teɪbəl ə kɑntɛns mæps pɹoʊlɑɡ: ɛmbɝz fɔlɪŋ ɑn dʒɹaɪ ɡɹæs wʌn wən læst saʊnz tu ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ θɹi ət ðə ɡɑɹɾənz fɔɹ eɪ dil faɪv sʌmθɪŋ . . . stʃɹeɪnʒ sɪks eɪ steɪv ən ə ɹeɪzɝ sɛvən eɪ koʊl mədæljən eɪt dʒɹæɡənz' ɛɡz naɪn eɪ ʃɔɹt pæθ tɛn eɪ vɪlədʒ ɪn ʃioʊɾə ɪlɛvən eɪ hɛl ɪn mɑɾɝɪn twɛlv eɪ mænjəfæktɝi θɝtin sidʒ fɔɹtin wɛt θɪŋz fɪftin eɪ dɪfɹən skɪl sɪkstin ðə nu fɑloʊɝ sɛvəntin eɪ bɹɑnz bɛɹ eɪtin nuz fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən naɪntin vaʊz twɛnti ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn twɛntiwʌn wɪðɪn ðə stoʊn twɛntiɾu tə meɪk ən æŋkɝ wip twɛntiθɹi kɔl tə ə sɪɾɪŋ twɛntifɔɹ hʌni ɪn ðə ti twɛntifaɪv ətɛndɪŋ ɪleɪɾə twɛntisɪks əz ɪf ðə wɝld wɝ fɑɡ twɛntisɛvən eɪ pleɪn wʊɾən bɑks twɛntieɪɾ ɪn mɔldən twɛntinaɪn ðə læs nɑt θɝɾi aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts θɝɾiwʌn ðə haʊs ɑn fʊl mun stʃɹit θɝɾitu tə kip ðə bɑɹɡən θɝɾiθɹi naɪn aʊɾ ə tɛn θɝɾifɔɹ eɪ kʌp ə kæf θɝɾifaɪv ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə daɪɛlɪn θɝɾisɪks ʌndɝ ən oʊk θɝɾisɛvən pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz ɛpəlɔɡ: ɹɪmɛmbɝ ði oʊl seɪɪŋ ɡlɔsɝi pɹeɪz fəɹ ðə ðə wil ə taɪm "ðə bæɾəl sinz əv ðə bɹɛθləs ɝdʒənsi ʌv fɝsthæn ɪkspɪɹiəns, ən ði . . . ivəl leɪst ɪndə ðə fɔɹsɪz ʌv ɡʊd, ðə deɪnʒɝz leɪɾənt ɪn ɛni pɹɑməst sælveɪʃən, ðə sɛns ə ði ʌnəvɔɪɾəbəl ɔnslɔɾ ʌv ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl ɪvɛns bɛɹ ðə mɑɹks ʌv əmɛɹəkən næʃənəl ɪkspɪɹiəns dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs θɹi dɛkeɪdz."

 -  loʊkəs "dʒɔɹɾənz tælən fəɹ səsteɪnɪŋ ðə dɪfəkəl kɑmbəneɪʃən ə səspɛns ən ɹɛzəluʃən, soʊ nɛsəsɛɹi ɪn ə mʌltɪvəljum sɪɹiz . . . ɪz nʌθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl."

 -  Locus "Jordan's talent for sustaining the difficult combination of suspense and resolution, so necessary in a multivolume series . . . is nothing short of remarkable."

 -  laɪbɹɛɹi dʒɝnəl "dʒɔɹɾən əz nɑt mɪɹli pʊɾ oʊld waɪn ɪndə nu bɑɾəlz: hiz kloʊðd oʊl boʊnz wɪð nu flɛʃ."

 -  Library Journal "Jordan has not merely put old wine into new bottles: He has clothed old bones with new flesh."

 -  ʃəkɑɡoʊ sʌn-taɪmz ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ stɔɹm ðə wil ə taɪm baɪ ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝl ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ðə ʃædoʊ ɹaɪzɪŋ ðə faɪɝz ə hɛvən lɔɹɾ ə keɪɑs eɪ kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz ðə pæθ ə dæɡɝz wɪntɝz hɑɹt kɹɔsɹoʊdz ə twaɪlaɪt naɪf ə dʒɹimz baɪ ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən ən bɹændən sændɝsən ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ stɔɹm taʊɝz ə mɪdnaɪt (fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ)

 -  Chicago Sun-Times THE GATHERING STORM THE WHEEL OF TIME by Robert Jordan The Eye of the World The Great Hunt The Dragon Reborn The Shadow Rising The Fires of Heaven Lord of Chaos A Crown of Swords The Path of Daggers Winter's Heart Crossroads of Twilight Knife of Dreams by Robert Jordan and Brandon Sanderson The Gathering Storm Towers of Midnight (forthcoming)

ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ stɔɹm ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən ən bɹændən sændɝsən eɪ tɑm doʊɝɾi əsoʊsiɪts bʊk nu jɔɹk noʊt: ɪf jə pɝtʃəs ðɪs bʊk wɪθaʊɾ ə kʌvɝ, jə ʃəd bi əwɛɹ ðət ðɪs bʊk ɪz stoʊlən pɹɑpɝɾi. ɪt wɑz ɹipɔɹɾəd əz "ənsoʊld ən dɪstʃɹɔɪd" tə ðə pʌblɪʃɝ, ən niðɝ ði ɔθɝ nɔɹ ðə pʌblɪʃɝ əz ɹəsivd ɛni peɪmən fəɹ ðɪs "stʃɹɪp bʊk."

THE GATHERING STORM ROBERT JORDAN AND BRANDON SANDERSON A TOM DOHERTY ASSOCIATES BOOK NEW YORK NOTE: If you purchased this book without a cover, you should be aware that this book is stolen property. It was reported as "unsold and destroyed" to the publisher, and neither the author nor the publisher has received any payment for this "stripped book."

ðɪs ɪz ə wɝk ə fɪkʃən. ɔl ə ðə kæɹɪktɝz, ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃənz, ən ɪvɛns pɔɹtʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ðɪs nɑvəl ɑɹ iðɝ pɹɑɾəkts ə ði ɔθɝz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən əɹ ɑɹ juz fɪktɪʃəsli.

This is a work of fiction. All of the characters, organizations, and events portrayed in this novel are either products of the author's imagination or are used fictitiously.

ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ stɔɹm kɑpiɹaɪt  tuθaʊzəndnaɪn baɪ ðə bændɝsnætʃ ɡɹup, ɪŋk.

ðə fɹeɪzəz "ðə wil ə taɪm" ən "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ən ðə sneɪk-wil sɪmbəl, ɑɹ tʃɹeɪdmɑɹks ə ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən.

ɔl ɹaɪts ɹɪzɝvd.

mæps baɪ ɛlisə mɪtʃəl ɪntɪɹiɝ ɪləstʃɹeɪʃənz baɪ mæθju si nilsən ən ɛlisə mɪtʃəl eɪ tɔɹ bʊk pʌblɪʃt baɪ tɑm doʊɝɾi əsoʊsiɪts,  wʌnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntifaɪv fɪfθ ævənu nu jɔɹk nujɔɹk wʌnzɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊwʌnzɪɹoʊ

Maps by Ellisa Mitchell Interior illustrations by Matthew C. Nielsen and Ellisa Mitchell A Tor Book Published by Tom Doherty Associates, LLC 175 Fifth Avenue New York NY 10010

 naɪnsɛvəneɪt-zɪɹoʊ-sɛvənθaʊzənsɪkshʌndʒɹədfɪftiθɹi-fɔɹwʌnfaɪvθɹi-tu

ISBN 978-0-7653-4153-2

fɝst ədɪʃən: noʊvɛmbɝ tuθaʊzəndnaɪn

First Edition: November 2009

fɝs mæs mɑɹkəɾ ədɪʃən: ɑktoʊbɝ twɛntiɾɛn

First Mass Market Edition: October 2010

pɹɪntəɾ ɪn ðə junaɪɾəd steɪts ʌv əmɛɹəkə zɪɹoʊ naɪn eɪt sɛvən sɪks faɪv fɔɹ θɹi tu wʌn

Printed in the United States of America 0 9 8 7 6 5 4 3 2 1

fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn noʊvɛmbɝ tuθaʊzənsɛvən, aɪ ɹəsivd ə foʊn kɔl ðət wəd tʃeɪnʒ maɪ laɪf fɝɛvɝ. hɛɹiət məkduɡəl, waɪf ən ɛɾətɝ ə ðə leɪt ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən, kɔl tə æsk mi ɪf aɪ wəd kəmplit ðə læs bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm.

FOREWORD In November 2007, I received a phone call that would change my life forever. Harriet McDougal, wife and editor of the late Robert Jordan, called to ask me if I would complete the last book of The Wheel of Time.

fəɹ ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt noʊ mɪstɝ dʒɔɹɾən hæd pæst əweɪ, ɪt peɪnz mi tə bi ðə wʌn tə bɹeɪk ðə nuz. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ aɪ fɛlt wən - waɪl aɪdli bɹaʊzɪŋ ði ɪntɝnɛɾ ɑn sɛptɛmbɝ sɪkstinθ, tuθaʊzənsɛvən - aɪ dɪskʌvɝd ðəɾ i hæd daɪd. aɪ wɑz ʃɑkt, stʌnd, ən dɪshɑɹɾənd. ðɪs wʌndɝfəl mæn, ə hɪɹoʊ tə mi ɪn maɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ kɝɪɹ, wɑz ɡɔn. ðə wɝl sʌɾənli bɪkeɪm ə dɪfɹən pleɪs.

For those who did not know Mr. Jordan had passed away, it pains me to be the one to break the news. I remember how I felt when - while idly browsing the Internet on September 16, 2007 - I discovered that he had died. I was shocked, stunned, and disheartened. This wonderful man, a hero to me in my writing career, was gone. The world suddenly became a different place.

aɪ fɝs pɪkt ʌp ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld ɪn naɪntinnaɪnti, wən aɪ wɑz ə tineɪdʒ fæntəsi ʌɾɪkt vɪzəɾɪŋ maɪ kɔɹnɝ bʊkstɔɹ. aɪ bɪkeɪm ə fæn ɪnstənli ən iɡɝli əweɪɾəd ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌnt. oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, aɪv ɹɛd ðə bʊks numɝəs taɪmz, ɔfən ɹeɪ-ɹiɾɪŋ ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɹiz wən ə nu bʊk wɑz ɹilist.

I first picked up The Eye of the World in 1990, when I was a teenage fantasy addict visiting my corner bookstore. I became a fan instantly and eagerly awaited The Great Hunt. Over the years, I've read the books numerous times, often re-reading the entire series when a new book was released.

taɪm pæst, ən aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd aɪ wɑntəd tə bɪkʌm ə fæntəsi ɔθɝ - ɪnfluənst, ɪn lɑɹdʒ pɑɹt, baɪ haʊ mʌtʃ aɪ lʌv ðə wil ə taɪm. ən jɛt, nɛvɝ dɪɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪ wəd wʌn deɪ ɡɛt ðət foʊn kɔl fɹəm hɛɹiət. ɪt keɪm tə mi əz ə kəmplit sɝpɹaɪz. aɪ hæd nɑɾ æskt, əplaɪd, əɹ dɛɹd wɪʃ fəɹ ðɪs ɑpɝtunəɾi - ðoʊ wən ðə ɹɪkwɛst wɑz meɪd, maɪ ænsɝ wɑz ɪmiɾiət. aɪ lʌv ðɪs sɪɹiz əz aɪ hæv lʌv nʌn ʌðɝ, ən ðə kæɹɪktɝz fil laɪk oʊld, dɪɹ fɹɛnz fɹəm maɪ tʃaɪldhʊd.

Time passed, and I decided I wanted to become a fantasy author - influenced, in large part, by how much I loved The Wheel of Time. And yet, never did I think that I would one day get that phone call from Harriet. It came to me as a complete surprise. I had not asked, applied, or dared wish for this opportunity - though when the request was made, my answer was immediate. I love this series as I have loved none other, and the characters feel like old, dear friends from my childhood.

aɪ kænɑt ɹipleɪs ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən. noʊbɑdi kəd ɹaɪt ðɪs bʊk əz wɛl əz i kəd hæv. ðəɾ ɪz ə sɪmpəl fækt. fɔɹtʃənətli, hi lɛf mɛni noʊts, aʊtlaɪnz, kəmpliɾəd sinz, ən dɪkteɪɾəd ɛkspləneɪʃənz wɪð ɪz waɪf ən əsɪstəns. bɪfɔɹ ɪz pæsɪŋ, hi æsk hɛɹiət tə faɪn sʌmwʌn tə kəmplit ðə sɪɹiz fəɹ ɪz fænz. hi lʌv jə ɔl vɛɹi mʌtʃ ən spɛn ðə vɛɹi læst wiks ə hɪz laɪf dɪkteɪɾɪŋ ɪvɛns fəɹ ðə faɪnəl vɑljum. ɪt wɑz tə bi kɔld eɪ mɛmɹi ʌv laɪt.

I cannot replace Robert Jordan. Nobody could write this book as well as he could have. That is a simple fact. Fortunately, he left many notes, outlines, completed scenes, and dictated explanations with his wife and assistants. Before his passing, he asked Harriet to find someone to complete the series for his fans. He loved you all very much and spent the very last weeks of his life dictating events for the final volume. It was to be called A Memory of Light.

eɪtin mʌnθs leɪɾɝ, wəɹ hɪɹ. mɪstɝ dʒɔɹɾən pɹɑməs ðət ðə faɪnəl bʊk wəd bi bɪɡ. bʌt ðə mænjəskɹɪp sun ɡɹu pɹoʊhɪbəɾɪvli hjudʒ; ɪt wəd bi θɹi taɪmz ðə saɪz ʌv ə ɹɛɡjəlɝ wil ə taɪm bʊk, ən ðə dɪsɪʒən wɑz meɪd baɪ hɛɹiəɾ ən tɔɹ tə splɪɾ eɪ mɛmɹi ʌv laɪɾ ɪndə θɝdz. ðəɹ wɝ sɛvɹəl ɛksələn bɹeɪkɪŋ pɔɪns ðət wəd ɡɪv ə fʊl ən kəmplit stɔɹi ɪn itʃ θɝd. jə meɪ θɪŋk ə ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ stɔɹm ən ɪts tu fɑloʊɝz əz ðə θɹi vɑljumz ʌv eɪ mɛmɹi ʌv laɪɾ əɹ əz ðə faɪnəl θɹi bʊks ə ðə wil ə taɪm. boʊθ ɑɹ kɝɛkt.

Eighteen months later, we are here. Mr. Jordan promised that the final book would be big. But the manuscript soon grew prohibitively huge; it would be three times the size of a regular Wheel of Time book, and the decision was made by Harriet and Tor to split A Memory of Light into thirds. There were several excellent breaking points that would give a full and complete story in each third. You may think of The Gathering Storm and its two followers as the three volumes of A Memory of Light or as the final three books of The Wheel of Time. Both are correct.

əz ə ðɪs ɹaɪɾɪŋ, aɪm hæfweɪ dʌn wɪð ðə sɛkən θɝd. wəɹ wɝkɪŋ əz kwɪkli əz ɪz ɹizənəbəl, ən wi doʊnt wɑn jə tə hæv tə weɪt tu lɔŋ tə ɡɛt ði ɛndɪŋ wi wɝ ɔl pɹɑməs nɪɹli twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ. (mɪstɝ dʒɔɹɾən dɪd ɹaɪt ðɪs ɛndɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ i pæst əweɪ, ən aɪ hæv ɹɛɾ ɪt. ən ɪts fæntæstɪk.) aɪ hæv nɑt tʃɹaɪd tə ɪməteɪt mɪstɝ dʒɔɹɾənz staɪl. ɪnstɛd, aɪv ədæptəd maɪ staɪl tə bi əpɹoʊpɹiət tə ðə wil ə taɪm. maɪ meɪn ɡoʊl wɑz tə steɪ tʃɹu tə ðə soʊlz ə ðə kæɹɪktɝz. ðə plɑɾ ɪz, ɪn lɑɹdʒ pɑɹt, ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾənz, ðoʊ mɛni ʌv ðə wɝdz ɑɹ maɪn. ɪmædʒən ðɪs bʊk əz ðə pɹɑɾəkt ʌv ə nu dɝɛktɝ wɝkɪŋ ɑn səm ə ðə sinz ʌv ə muvi waɪl ɹɪteɪnɪŋ ðə seɪm æktɝz ən skɹɪpt.

As of this writing, I am halfway done with the second third. We are working as quickly as is reasonable, and we don't want you to have to wait too long to get the ending we were all promised nearly twenty years ago. (Mr. Jordan did write this ending himself before he passed away, and I have read it. And it is fantastic.) I have not tried to imitate Mr. Jordan's style. Instead, I've adapted my style to be appropriate to The Wheel of Time. My main goal was to stay true to the souls of the characters. The plot is, in large part, Robert Jordan's, though many of the words are mine. Imagine this book as the product of a new director working on some of the scenes of a movie while retaining the same actors and script.

bʌt ðɪs ɪz ə bɪɡ pɹɑdʒɛkt, ən ɪɾəl teɪk taɪm tə kəmplit. aɪ bɛɡ jəɹ peɪʃəns əz wi spɛn ðiz nɛks fju jɪɹz pɝfɛktɪŋ ðɪs stɔɹi. wi hoʊld ɪn əɹ hænz ði ɛndɪŋ ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst fæntəsi ɛpɪk ʌv əɹ taɪm, ən aɪ ɪntɛn tə si ɪt dʌn ɹaɪt. aɪ ɪntɛn tə ɹɪmeɪn tʃɹu tə mɪstɝ dʒɔɹɾənz wɪʃɪz ən noʊts.

But this is a big project, and it will take time to complete. I beg your patience as we spend these next few years perfecting this story. We hold in our hands the ending of the greatest fantasy epic of our time, and I intend to see it done right. I intend to remain true to Mr. Jordan's wishes and notes.

maɪ ɑɹtɪstɪk ɪntɛɡɹəɾi, ən lʌv fəɹ ðə bʊks, wɪl nɑt lemi də ɛniθɪŋ lɛs. ɪn ði ɛnd, aɪ lɛt ðə wɝdz hɪɹɪn stæn əz ðə bɛst ɑɹɡjəmən fəɹ wʌt wəɹ duɪŋ.

My artistic integrity, and love for the books, will not let me do anything less. In the end, I let the words herein stand as the best argument for what we are doing.

ðɪs ɪz nɑt maɪ bʊk. ɪts ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾənz bʊk, ən tə ə lɛsɝ ɪkstɛnt, ɪts jəɹ bʊk.

This is not my book. It is Robert Jordan's book, and to a lesser extent, it is your book.

θæŋk jə fəɹ ɹɛɾɪŋ.

Thank you for reading.

bɹændən sændɝsən dʒun tuθaʊzəndnaɪn

BRANDON SANDERSON June 2009

fəɹ mɝiə saɪmənz ən ælən ɹoʊmæntʃək, wɪθaʊt hum ðɪs bʊk wʊdn əv bɪn pɑsəbəl kɑntɛns mæps pɹoʊlɑɡ: wʌt ðə stɔɹm minz wʌn tɪɹz fɹəm stil tu ðə neɪtʃɝ ə peɪn θɹi ðə weɪz ʌv ɑnɝ fɔɹ naɪtfɔl faɪv eɪ teɪl ə blʌd sɪks wən aɪɝn mɛls sɛvən ðə plæn fəɹ ɑɹæd dumən eɪt klin ʃɝts naɪn livɪŋ mɔldən tɛn ðə læst ə ðə təbæk ɪlɛvən ðə dɛθ ʌv ɑdʒɹɪn twɛlv ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ ɪnkaʊntɝz θɝtin ən ɔfɝ ən ə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ fɔɹtin eɪ bɑks oʊpənz fɪftin eɪ pleɪs tə bɪɡɪn sɪkstin ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ sɛvəntin kwɛstʃənz ə kəntʃɹoʊl eɪtin eɪ mɛsədʒ ɪn heɪs naɪntin ɡæmbəts twɛnti ɑn ə bɹoʊkən ɹoʊd twɛntiwʌn ɛmbɝz ən æʃ twɛntiɾu ðə læs ðət kəd bi dʌn twɛntiθɹi eɪ wɔɹp ɪn ði ɛɹ twɛntifɔɹ eɪ nu kəmɪtmən twɛntifaɪv ɪn dɑɹknəs twɛntisɪks eɪ kɹæk ɪn ðə stoʊn twɛntisɛvən ðə tɪpsi ɡɛldɪŋ twɛntieɪt naɪɾ ɪn hɪndɝstæp twɛntinaɪn ɪndə bændɑɹ ɛbən θɝɾi oʊld ædvaɪs θɝɾiwʌn eɪ pɹɑməs tə luz θɝɪn θɝɾitu ɹɪvɝz ə ʃædoʊ θɝɾiθɹi eɪ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən θɝɾifɔɹ lɛdʒənz θɝɾifaɪv eɪ heɪloʊ ʌv blæknəs θɝɾisɪks ðə dɛθ ə tuɑn θɝɾisɛvən eɪ fɔɹs ə laɪt θɝɾieɪt nuz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd θɝɾinaɪn eɪ vɪzət fɹəm vɛɹɪn sədaɪ fɔɹɾi ðə taʊɝ ʃeɪks fɔɹɾiwʌn eɪ faʊn ə paʊɝ fɔɹɾitu bɪfɔɹ ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ fɔɹɾiθɹi sil tə ðə fleɪm fɔɹɾifɔɹ sɛns ənnoʊn fɔɹɾifaɪv ðə taʊɝ stænz fɔɹɾisɪks tə bi fɔɹdʒd əɡɛn fɔɹɾisɛvən ðə wʌn i lɔs fɔɹɾieɪt ɹiɾɪŋ ðə kɑməntɛɹi fɔɹɾinaɪn dʒʌst ənʌðɝ mæn fɪfti veɪnz ʌv ɡoʊld ɛpəlɔɡ: beɪðd ɪn laɪt ɡlɔsɝi ɹeɪvənz ən kɹoʊz. ɹæts. mɪsts ən klaʊdz. ɪnsɛks ən kɝʌpʃən. stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪvɛns ən ɑɾ əkɝənsɪz. ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi twɪstəɾ ən stʃɹeɪnʒ. wʌndɝz!

For Maria Simons and Alan Romanczuk, without whom this book wouldn't have been possible CONTENTS MAPS PROLOGUE: What the Storm Means 1 Tears from Steel 2 The Nature of Pain 3 The Ways of Honor 4 Nightfall 5 A Tale of Blood 6 When Iron Melts 7 The Plan for Arad Doman 8 Clean Shirts 9 Leaving Malden 10 The Last of the Tabac 11 The Death of Adrin 12 Unexpected Encounters 13 An Offer and a Departure 14 A Box Opens 15 A Place to Begin 16 In the White Tower 17 Questions of Control 18 A Message in Haste 19 Gambits 20 On a Broken Road 21 Embers and Ash 22 The Last That Could Be Done 23 A Warp in the Air 24 A New Commitment 25 In Darkness 26 A Crack in the Stone 27 The Tipsy Gelding 28 Night in Hinderstap 29 Into Bandar Eban 30 Old Advice 31 A Promise to Lews Therin 32 Rivers of Shadow 33 A Conversation with the Dragon 34 Legends 35 A Halo of Blackness 36 The Death of Tuon 37 A Force of Light 38 News in Tel'aran'rhiod 39 A Visit from Verin Sedai 40 The Tower Shakes 41 A Fount of Power 42 Before the Stone of Tear 43 Sealed to the Flame 44 Scents Unknown 45 The Tower Stands 46 To Be Forged Again 47 The One He Lost 48 Reading the Commentary 49 Just Another Man 50 Veins of Gold EPILOGUE: Bathed in Light GLOSSARY Ravens and crows. Rats. Mists and clouds. Insects and corruption. Strange events and odd occurrences. The ordinary twisted and strange. Wonders!

ðə dɛɾ ɑɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wɔk, ən səm si ðɛm. ʌðɝz də nɑt, bʌt mɔɹ ən mɔɹ, wi ɔl fɪɹ ðə naɪt.

The dead are beginning to walk, and some see them. Others do not, but more and more, we all fear the night.

ðiz əv bɪn əɹ deɪz. ðeɪ ɹeɪn əpɑn əs bɪniθ ə dɛd skaɪ, kɹʌʃɪŋ əs wɪð ðɛɹ fjʊɹi, əntɪl əz wʌn wi bɛɡ: "lɛɾ ɪt bɪɡɪn!"

These have been our days. They rain upon us beneath a dead sky, crushing us with their fury, until as one we beg: "Let it begin!"

 - dʒɝnəl ə ði ənnoʊn skɑlɝ, ɛntʃɹi fəɹ ðə fist ə fɹiə, wʌnθaʊzənd ni ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ stɔɹm 
 - Journal of the Unknown Scholar, entry for The Feast of Freia, 1000 NE THE GATHERING STORM 
pɹoʊlɑɡ wʌt ðə stɔɹm minz



PROLOGUE What the Storm Means

ɹɪnəl fænwɔɹ sæɾ ɑn ɪz pɔɹtʃ, wɔɹmɪŋ ðə stɝɾi blækoʊk tʃɛɹ kɹæftɪd fəɹ ɪm baɪ hɪz ɡɹændsʌn tu jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ. hi stɛɹd nɔɹθwɝd.

Renald Fanwar sat on his porch, warming the sturdy blackoak chair crafted for him by his grandson two years before. He stared northward.

ət ðə blæk ən sɪlvɝ klaʊdz.

At the black and silver clouds.

hid nɛvɝ sin ðɛɹ laɪk bɪfɔɹ. ðeɪ blæŋkəɾɪd ði ɪntaɪɝ hɝaɪzən tə ðə nɔɹθ, haɪ ɪn ðə skaɪ.

He'd never seen their like before. They blanketed the entire horizon to the north, high in the sky.

ðeɪ wɝnt ɡɹeɪ. ðeɪ wɝ blæk ən sɪlvɝ. dɑɹk, ɹʌmbəlɪŋ θʌndɝhɛdz, əz dɑɹk əz ə ɹut sɛlɝ ət mɪdnaɪt. wɪð stʃɹaɪkɪŋ sɪlvɝ laɪt bɹeɪkɪŋ bɪtwin ðɛm, flæʃɪz ə laɪtnɪŋ ðət ɡeɪv ɔf noʊ saʊnd.

They weren't gray. They were black and silver. Dark, rumbling thunderheads, as dark as a root cellar at midnight. With striking silver light breaking between them, flashes of lightning that gave off no sound.

ði ɛɹ wɑz θɪk. θɪk wɪð ðə sɛns ə dʌst ən dɝt. ʌv dʒɹaɪd livz ən ɹeɪn ðət ɹəfjuz tə fɔl. spɹɪŋ hæd kʌm. ən jɛɾ ɪz kɹɑps dɪdnt ɡɹoʊ. nɑɾ ə spɹaʊt hæd dɛɹd poʊk θɹu ði ɝθ.

The air was thick. Thick with the scents of dust and dirt. Of dried leaves and rain that refused to fall. Spring had come. And yet his crops didn't grow. Not a sprout had dared poke through the earth.

hi ɹoʊz sloʊli fɹəm ɪz tʃɛɹ, wʊd kɹikɪŋ, tʃɛɹ ɹɑkɪŋ sɔfli bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən wɔkt ʌp tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə pɔɹtʃ. hi tʃuɾ ɑn ɪz paɪp, ðoʊ ɪts faɪɝ hæd ɡɔn aʊt. hi kʊdn bi bɑðɝd tə ɹɪlaɪɾ ɪt. ðoʊz klaʊdz tʃɹænsfɪks hɪm. ðeɪ wɝ soʊ blæk. laɪk ðə smoʊk ʌv ə bɹʌʃfaɪɝ, oʊnli noʊ bɹʌʃfaɪɝ smoʊk ɛvɝ ɹoʊz ðət haɪ ʌp ɪn ði ɛɹ. ən wʌt tə meɪk ə sɪlvɝ klaʊdz? bʌlʒɪŋ bɪtwin ðə blæk wʌnz, laɪk pleɪsəz wɛɹ pɑlɪʃt stil ʃoʊn θɹu mɛɾəl kɹʌstɪd wɪð sʊt.

He rose slowly from his chair, wood creaking, chair rocking softly behind him, and walked up to the edge of the porch. He chewed on his pipe, though its fire had gone out. He couldn't be bothered to relight it. Those clouds transfixed him. They were so black. Like the smoke of a brushfire, only no brushfire smoke ever rose that high up in the air. And what to make of silver clouds? Bulging between the black ones, like places where polished steel shone through metal crusted with soot.

hi ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn, ɡlænsɪŋ daʊn əɾ ɪz jɑɹd. ə smɔl, waɪtwɑʃt fɛns kənteɪn ə pætʃ ʌv ɡɹæs ən ʃɹʌbz. ðə ʃɹʌbz wɝ dɛd naʊ, ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm. hædn læstəd θɹu ðət wɪntɝ.

He rubbed his chin, glancing down at his yard. A small, whitewashed fence contained a patch of grass and shrubs. The shrubs were dead now, every one of them. Hadn't lasted through that winter.

hid nid tə pʊl əm aʊt sun. ən ðə ɡɹæs . . . wɛl, ðə ɡɹæs wɑz stɪl dʒʌst wɪntɝ θætʃ. nɑɾ ivən ɛni widz spɹaʊɾəd.

He'd need to pull them out soon. And the grass . . . well, the grass was still just winter thatch. Not even any weeds sprouted.

ə klæp ə θʌndɝ ʃʊk hɪm. pjʊɹ, ʃɑɹp, laɪk ən ɪnɔɹməs kɹæʃ ə mɛɾəl əɡɛns mɛɾəl. ɪt ɹæɾəld ðə wɪndoʊz ə ðə haʊs, ʃʊk ðə pɔɹtʃ bɔɹdz, sim tə vaɪbɹeɪɾ ɪz vɛɹi boʊnz.

A clap of thunder shook him. Pure, sharp, like an enormous crash of metal against metal. It rattled the windows of the house, shook the porch boards, seemed to vibrate his very bones.

hi dʒʌmp bæk. ðət stʃɹaɪk hæd bɪn kloʊs - pɝhæps ɑn ɪz pɹɑpɝɾi. hi ɪtʃt tə ɡoʊ ɪnspɛk ðə dæmədʒ. laɪtnɪŋ faɪɝ kəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ə mæn, bɝn ɪm aʊɾ ə hɪz lænd. ʌp hɪɹ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, soʊ mɛni θɪŋz wɝ ʌnɪntɛnʃənəl tɪndɝ - dʒɹaɪ ɡɹæs, dʒɹaɪ ʃɪŋɡəlz, dʒɹaɪ sid.

He jumped back. That strike had been close - perhaps on his property. He itched to go inspect the damage. Lightning fire could destroy a man, burn him out of his land. Up here in the Borderlands, so many things were unintentional tinder - dry grass, dry shingles, dry seed.

bʌt ðə klaʊdz wɝ stɪl dɪstənt. ðət stʃɹaɪk kʊdn əv bɪn ɑn ɪz pɹɑpɝɾi. ðə sɪlvɝ ən blæk θʌndɝhɛdz ɹoʊld ən bɔɪld, fiɾɪŋ ən kənsumɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz.

But the clouds were still distant. That strike couldn't have been on his property. The silver and black thunderheads rolled and boiled, feeding and consuming themselves.

hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, kɑmɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ. hæɾ i ɪmædʒən ðə θʌndɝ? wɑz i ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf ðə saɪd, əz ɡæfɪn ɔlweɪz dʒoʊkt? hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz.

He closed his eyes, calming himself, taking a deep breath. Had he imagined the thunder? Was he going off the side, as Gaffin always joked? He opened his eyes.

ən ðə klaʊdz wɝ ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, dɝɛkli əbʌv ɪz haʊs.

And the clouds were right there, directly above his house.

ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd sʌɾənli ɹoʊl fɔɹwɝd, ɪntɛndɪŋ tə stʃɹaɪk waɪl ɪz ɡeɪz wɑz əvɝɾəd. ðeɪ dɑməneɪɾəd ðə skaɪ naʊ, swipɪŋ dɪstənli ɪn iðɝ dɝɛkʃən, mæsɪv ən oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðɛɹ weɪt pɹɛsɪŋ ði ɛɹ daʊn ɝaʊn hɪm. hi dʒɹu ɪn ə bɹɛθ ðət wɑz hɛvi wɪð sʌɾən hjumɪɾəti, ən ɪz bɹaʊ pɹɪkəld wɪð swɛt.

It was as if they had suddenly rolled forward, intending to strike while his gaze was averted. They dominated the sky now, sweeping distantly in either direction, massive and overwhelming. He could almost feel their weight pressing the air down around him. He drew in a breath that was heavy with sudden humidity, and his brow prickled with sweat.

ðoʊz klaʊdz tʃɝnd, dɑɹk blæk ən sɪlvɝ θʌndɝhɛdz ʃeɪkɪŋ wɪð waɪt blæsts. ðeɪ sʌɾənli bɔɪl daʊnwɝd, laɪk ðə fʌnəl klaʊɾ ʌv ə twɪstɝ, kʌmɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. hi kɹaɪɾ aʊt, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hænd, əz ə mæn maɪt bɪfɔɹ ə paʊɝfli bɹaɪt laɪt. ðət blæknəs. ðəɾ ɛnləs, sʌfəkeɪɾɪŋ blæknəs. ɪt wəd teɪk hɪm. hi nu.

Those clouds churned, dark black and silver thunderheads shaking with white blasts. They suddenly boiled downward, like the funnel cloud of a twister, coming for him. He cried out, raising a hand, as a man might before a powerfully bright light. That blackness. That endless, suffocating blackness. It would take him. He knew.

ən ðən ðə klaʊdz wɝ ɡɔn.

And then the clouds were gone.

hɪz paɪp hɪt ðə pɔɹtʃəz flɔɹbɔɹdz, klɪkɪŋ sɔfli, tɔsɪŋ bɝn təbæk aʊɾ ɪn ə spɹeɪ əkɹɔs ðə stɛps. hi hædn ɹilaɪz hid lɛɾ ɪt slɪp fɹi. ɹɪnəl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɛmpti blu skaɪ, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz kɹɪŋɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ.

His pipe hit the porch's floorboards, clicking softly, tossing burned tabac out in a spray across the steps. He hadn't realized he'd let it slip free. Renald hesitated, looking up at empty blue sky, realizing that he was cringing at nothing.

ðə klaʊdz wɝ ɔf ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən əɡɛn, səm fɔɹɾi liɡz dɪstənt. ðeɪ θʌndɝd sɔfli.

The clouds were off on the horizon again, some forty leagues distant. They thundered softly.

hi pɪkt ʌp ɪz paɪp wɪð ə ʃeɪkɪŋ hænd, spɑɾəd fɹəm eɪdʒ, tæn fɹəm jɪɹz spɛn ɪn ðə sʌn.

He picked up his pipe with a shaking hand, spotted from age, tanned from years spent in the sun.

dʒʌst ə tʃɹɪk ə jəɹ maɪnd, ɹɪnəld, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf ðə saɪd, ʃʊɹ əz ɛɡz ɪz ɛɡz.

Just a trick of your mind, Renald, he told himself. You're going off the side, sure as eggs is eggs.

hi wɑz ɑn ɛdʒ kəz ə ðə kɹɑps. ðət hæɾ ɪm ɑn ɛdʒ. ðoʊ hi spoʊk ɑptəmɪstɪk wɝdz fəɹ ðə lædz, ɪt dʒʌst wɑznt nætʃɹəl. sʌmθɪŋ ʃʊɾə spɹaʊɾəd baɪ naʊ. hid fɑɹm ðət læn fəɹ fɔɹɾi jɪɹz! bɑɹli dɪdn teɪk ðɪs lɔŋ tə spɹaʊt. bɝn hɪm, bʌɾ ɪt dɪdnt. wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə wɝl ðiz deɪz? plæns kʊdn bi dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn tə spɹaʊt, ən klaʊdz dɪdn steɪ wɛɹ ðeɪ ʃʊd.

He was on edge because of the crops. That had him on edge. Though he spoke optimistic words for the lads, it just wasn't natural. Something should have sprouted by now. He'd farmed that land for forty years! Barley didn't take this long to sprout. Burn him, but it didn't. What was going on in the world these days? Plants couldn't be depended on to sprout, and clouds didn't stay where they should.

hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə sɪt bæk daʊn ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ, lɛɡz ʃeɪkɪŋ. ɡɛɾɪŋ oʊld, aɪ æm. . . . hi θɔt.

He forced himself to sit back down in his chair, legs shaking. Getting old, I am. . . . he thought.

hid wɝkt ə fɑɹm ɔl ə hɪz laɪf. fɑɹmstɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz wɑz nɑɾ izi, bʌɾ ɪf jə wɝk hɑɹd, jə kəd ɡɹoʊ ə səksɛsfəl laɪf waɪl jə ɡɹu stʃɹɔŋ kɹɑps. "ə mæn əz əz mʌtʃ lʌk əz hiz sidz ɪn ðə fild," hɪz fɑðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz sɛd.

He'd worked a farm all of his life. Farmsteading in the Borderlands was not easy, but if you worked hard, you could grow a successful life while you grew strong crops. "A man has as much luck as he has seeds in the field," his father had always said.

wɛl, ɹɪnəld wɑz wʌn ə ðə moʊst səksɛsfəl fɑɹmɝz ɪn ði ɛɹiə. hid dʌn wɛl ɪnʌf tə baɪ aʊt ðə tu fɑɹmz bɪsaɪd hɪz, ən i kəd ɹʌn θɝɾi wæɡənz tə mɑɹkəɾ itʃ fɔl. hi naʊ hæd sɪks ɡʊd mɛn wɝkɪŋ fəɹ hɪm, plaʊɪŋ ðə filz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðə fɛnsəz. nɑt ðəɾ i dɪdn əv tə klaɪm daʊn ɪn ðə mʌk ɛvɹi deɪ ən ʃoʊ ðɛm wʌt ɡʊd fɑɹmɪŋ wɑz ɔl əbaʊt. jə kʊdn lɛɾ ə lɪɾəl səksɛs ɹuən ju.

Well, Renald was one of the most successful farmers in the area. He'd done well enough to buy out the two farms beside his, and he could run thirty wagons to market each fall. He now had six good men working for him, plowing the fields, riding the fences. Not that he didn't have to climb down in the muck every day and show them what good farming was all about. You couldn't let a little success ruin you.

jɛs, hid wɝk ðə lænd, lɪv ðə lænd, əz ɪz fɑðɝ ɔlweɪz juz tə seɪ. hi ʌndɝstʊd ðə wɛðɝ əz wɛl əz ə mæn kʊd. ðoʊz klaʊdz wɝnt nætʃɹəl. ðeɪ ɹʌmbəl sɔfli, laɪk ən ænəməl ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ɑn ə dɑɹk naɪt. weɪɾɪŋ. lɝkɪŋ ɪn ðə nɪɹbaɪ wʊdz.

Yes, he'd worked the land, lived the land, as his father always used to say. He understood the weather as well as a man could. Those clouds weren't natural. They rumbled softly, like an animal growling on a dark night. Waiting. Lurking in the nearby woods.

hi dʒʌmpt əɾ ənʌðɝ kɹæʃ ə θʌndɝ ðət sim tu kloʊs. wɝ ðoʊz klaʊdz fɔɹɾi liɡz əweɪ? ɪz ðət wʌt hid θɔt? lʊk mɔɹ laɪk tɛn liɡz əweɪ, naʊ ðəɾ i stʌɾid ðɛm.

He jumped at another crash of thunder that seemed too close. Were those clouds forty leagues away? Is that what he'd thought? Looked more like ten leagues away, now that he studied them.

"doʊnt ɡɛt laɪk ðæt," hi ɡɹʌmbəld ət hɪmsɛlf. hɪz oʊn vɔɪs saʊndəd ɡʊd tə hɪm. ɹil. ɪt wɑz naɪs tə hɪɹ sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ðət ɹʌmbəlɪŋ ən ði əkeɪʒənəl kɹik ə ʃʌɾɝz ɪn ðə wɪnd.

"Don't get like that," he grumbled at himself. His own voice sounded good to him. Real. It was nice to hear something other than that rumbling and the occasional creak of shutters in the wind.

ʃʊdn i bi eɪbəl tə hɪɹ oʊeɪn ɪnsaɪd, ɡɛɾɪŋ sʌpɝ ɹɛɾi?

Shouldn't he be able to hear Auaine inside, getting supper ready?

"jɔɹ taɪɝd. ðæts ɪt. taɪɝd." hi fɪʃt ɪn ɪz vɛs pɑkəɾ ən pʊld aʊɾ ɪz təbæk paʊtʃ.

"You're tired. That's it. Tired." He fished in his vest pocket and pulled out his tabac pouch.

ə feɪn ɹʌmbəlɪŋ keɪm fɹəm ðə ɹaɪt. ət fɝst, hi əsumd ɪt wɑz ðə θʌndɝ. haʊɛvɝ, ðɪs ɹʌmbəlɪŋ wɑz tu ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ, tu ɹɛɡjəlɝ. ðət wɑzn θʌndɝ. ɪt wɑz wilz tɝnɪŋ.

A faint rumbling came from the right. At first, he assumed it was the thunder. However, this rumbling was too grating, too regular. That wasn't thunder. It was wheels turning.

ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, ə lɑɹdʒ, ɑksən-dʒɹɔn wæɡən kɹɛstəd mælɝdz hɪl, dʒʌs tə ði ist. ɹɪnəl hæd neɪm ðət hɪl hɪmsɛlf. ɛvɹi ɡʊd hɪl niɾəd ə neɪm. ðə ɹoʊd wɑz mælɝdz ɹoʊd. soʊ waɪ nɑt neɪm ðə hɪl ðət tu?

Sure enough, a large, oxen-drawn wagon crested Mallard's Hill, just to the east. Renald had named that hill himself. Every good hill needed a name. The road was Mallard's Road. So why not name the hill that too?

hi lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ, pɔɪntɪdli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðoʊz klaʊdz əz i skwɪntɪd təwɔɹd ðə wæɡən, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aʊt ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz feɪs. θulɪn? ðə smɪθ? wʌt wɑz i duɪŋ, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ə wæɡən leɪɾən hæfweɪ tə ðə hɛvənz? hi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi wɝkɪŋ ɑn ɹɪnəlz nu plaʊ!

He leaned forward in his chair, pointedly ignoring those clouds as he squinted toward the wagon, trying to make out the driver's face. Thulin? The smith? What was he doing, driving a wagon laden halfway to the heavens? He was supposed to be working on Renald's new plow!

lin fəɹ wʌn ə hɪz tʃɹeɪd, θulɪn wɑz stɪl twaɪs əz mʌsəld əz moʊs fɑɹmhænz. hi hæd ðə dɑɹk hɛɹ ən tæn skɪn ʌv ə ʃaɪnɝən, ən kɛpt ɪz feɪs ʃeɪvd æftɝ ðɛɹ fæʃən, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ðə tɑpnɑt. θulɪnz fæmli maɪt tʃɹeɪs ɪts ɹuts bæk tə bɔɹɾɝlənd wɔɹiɝz, bʌɾ i hɪmsɛlf wɑz dʒʌst ə sɪmpəl kʌntʃɹi mæn laɪk ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm. hi ɹæn ðə smɪθi oʊvɝ ɪn oʊk wɔɾɝ, faɪv maɪlz tə ði ist.

Lean for one of his trade, Thulin was still twice as muscled as most farmhands. He had the dark hair and tan skin of a Shienaran, and kept his face shaved after their fashion, but he did not wear the topknot. Thulin's family might trace its roots back to Borderland warriors, but he himself was just a simple country man like the rest of them. He ran the smithy over in Oak Water, five miles to the east.

ɹɪnəl hæɾ ɛndʒɔɪd mɛni ə ɡeɪm ə stoʊnz wɪð ðə smɪθ dʊɹɪŋ wɪntɝ ivnɪŋz.

Renald had enjoyed many a game of stones with the smith during winter evenings.

θulɪn wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn - hi hædn sin əz mɛni jɪɹz əz ɹɪnəld, bʌt ðə læs fju wɪntɝz hæd pɹɑmptəd θulɪn tə stɑɹt spikɪŋ ə ɹitaɪɝmənt. smɪθɪŋ wɑzn ən oʊl mænz tʃɹeɪd. ʌv kɔɹs, niðɝ wɑz fɑɹmɪŋ. wɝ ðəɹ ɹɪli ɛni oʊl mænz tʃɹeɪdz?

Thulin was getting on - he hadn't seen as many years as Renald, but the last few winters had prompted Thulin to start speaking of retirement. Smithing wasn't an old man's trade. Of course, neither was farming. Were there really any old man's trades?

θulɪnz wæɡən əpɹoʊtʃt əlɔŋ ðə pækt ɝθən ɹoʊd, əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɹɪnəlz waɪt-fɛns jɑɹd. naʊ, ðæts ɑd, ɹɪnəl θɔt. bɪhaɪn ðə wæɡən tʃɹeɪld ə nit stʃɹɪŋ ʌv ænəməlz: faɪv ɡoʊts ən tu mɪlkoʊz. kɹeɪts ə blæk-fɛðɝd tʃɪkənz wɝ taɪɾ ɑn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə wæɡən, ən ðə bɛɾ ə ðə wæɡən ɪtsɛlf wɑz paɪl fʊl ə fɝnɪtʃɝ, sæks ən bæɹəlz. θulɪnz juθfəl dɔɾɝ, mɪɹɑlə, sæɾ ɑn ðə sit wɪð hɪm, nɛks tə hɪz waɪf, ə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən fɹəm ðə saʊθ. twɛnti-faɪv jɪɹz θulɪnz waɪf, bʌt ɹɪnəl stɪl θɔɾ ʌv ɡæænhə əz "ðæt sʌðɝn ɡɝl."

Thulin's wagon approached along the packed earthen road, approaching Renald's white-fenced yard. Now, that's odd, Renald thought. Behind the wagon trailed a neat string of animals: five goats and two milkcows. Crates of black-feathered chickens were tied on the outside of the wagon, and the bed of the wagon itself was piled full of furniture, sacks and barrels. Thulin's youthful daughter, Mirala, sat on the seat with him, next to his wife, a golden-haired woman from the south. Twenty-five years Thulin's wife, but Renald still thought of Gallanha as "that southern girl."

ðə hoʊl fæmli wɑz ɪn ðə wæɡən, liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ bɛs laɪvstɑk. ɑbviəsli ɑn ðə muv. bʌt wɛɹ? ɔf tə vɪzət ɹɛləɾɪvz, pɝhæps? hi ən θulɪn hædn pleɪɾ ə ɹaʊn ə stoʊnz ɪn . . . oʊ, θɹi wiks naʊ. nɑt mʌtʃ taɪm fəɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ, wʌt wɪð ðə kʌmɪŋ ə spɹɪŋ ən ðə hɝid plæntɪŋ.

The whole family was in the wagon, leading their best livestock. Obviously on the move. But where? Off to visit relatives, perhaps? He and Thulin hadn't played a round of stones in . . . oh, three weeks now. Not much time for visiting, what with the coming of spring and the hurried planting.

sʌmwʌn wəd nid tə mɛn ðə plaʊz ən ʃɑɹpən ðə saɪθz. hu wəd də ɪɾ ɪf θulɪnz smɪθi wɛn koʊld?

Someone would need to mend the plows and sharpen the scythes. Who would do it if Thulin's smithy went cold?

ɹɪnəl tʌkt ə pɪntʃ ə təbæk ɪndə hɪz paɪp əz θulɪn pʊl ðə wæɡən ʌp bɪsaɪd ɹɪnəlz jɑɹd.

Renald tucked a pinch of tabac into his pipe as Thulin pulled the wagon up beside Renald's yard.

ðə lin, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd smɪθ hændəd ðə ɹeɪnz tə hɪz dɔɾɝ, ðən klaɪm daʊn fɹəm ðə wæɡən, fit θɹoʊɪŋ pʌfs ə dʌst ɪndə ði ɛɹ wən i hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊnd. bɪhaɪn ɪm ðə dɪstən stɔɹm stɪl bɹud.

The lean, gray-haired smith handed the reins to his daughter, then climbed down from the wagon, feet throwing puffs of dust into the air when he hit the ground. Behind him the distant storm still brewed.

θulɪn pʊʃt oʊpən ðə fɛns ɡeɪt, ðən stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ðə pɔɹtʃ. hi lʊk dɪstʃɹæktəd. ɹɪnəld oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə ɡɪv ɡɹiɾɪŋ, bʌt θulɪn spoʊk fɝst.

Thulin pushed open the fence gate, then strode up to the porch. He looked distracted. Renald opened his mouth to give greeting, but Thulin spoke first.

"aɪ bɛɹid maɪ bɛst ænvəl ɪn ɡæænhəz oʊl stʃɹɔbɛɹi pætʃ, ɹɪnəld," ðə bɪɡ smɪθ sɛd. "ju ɹɪmɛmbɝ wɛɹ ðəɾ ɪz, doʊn ju? aɪ pæk maɪ bɛst sɛɾ ə tulz ðəɹ əz wɛl. ðəɹ wɛl ɡɹist ən ɪnsaɪd maɪ bɛs tʃɛst, laɪn tə kip ɪt dʒɹaɪ. ðət ʃəd kip ðə ɹʌst ɔf ə ðɛm. fəɹ ə taɪm ət list."

"I buried my best anvil in Gallanha's old strawberry patch, Renald," the big smith said. "You remember where that is, don't you? I packed my best set of tools there as well. They're well greased and inside my best chest, lined to keep it dry. That should keep the rust off of them. For a time at least."

ɹɪnəl kloʊzd ɪz maʊθ, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz paɪp hæf-fʊl. ɪf θulɪn wɑz bɛɹiɪŋ ɪz ænvəl . . . wɛl, ɪt mɛn i wɑzn plænɪŋ tə kʌm bæk fəɹ ə waɪl. "θulɪn, wʌt - "

Renald closed his mouth, holding his pipe half-full. If Thulin was burying his anvil . . . well, it meant he wasn't planning to come back for a while. "Thulin, what - "

"ɪf aɪ doʊn ɹɪtɝn," θulɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd, "wʊd jə dɪɡ maɪ θɪŋz aʊɾ ən si ðət ðəɹ kɛɹd fɔɹ? sɛl əm tə sʌmwʌn u kɛɹz, ɹɪnəld. aɪ wʊdn əv dʒʌst ɛniwʌn biɾɪŋ ðəɾ ænvəl. tʊk mi twɛnti jɪɹz tə ɡæðɝ ðoʊz tulz, jə noʊ."

"If I don't return," Thulin said, glancing northward, "would you dig my things out and see that they're cared for? Sell them to someone who cares, Renald. I wouldn't have just anyone beating that anvil. Took me twenty years to gather those tools, you know."

"bʌt θulɪn!" ɹɪnəl spʌɾɝd. "wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?"

"But Thulin!" Renald sputtered. "Where are you going?"

θulɪn tɝn bæk tə hɪm, linɪŋ wʌn ɑɹm ɑn ðə pɔɹtʃ ɹeɪlɪŋ, ðoʊz bɹaʊn aɪz ə hɪz sɑləm.

Thulin turned back to him, leaning one arm on the porch railing, those brown eyes of his solemn.

"ðɛɹz ə stɔɹm kʌmɪŋ," hi sɛd. "æn soʊ aɪ fɪɡjɝ aɪv ɡɑt tə hɛɾ ɑn tə ðə nɔɹθ."

"There's a storm coming," he said. "And so I figure I've got to head on to the north."

"stɔɹm?" ɹɪnəld æskt. "ðæt wʌn ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən, jə min? θulɪn, ɪt lʊks bæd - bɝn maɪ boʊnz, bʌɾ ɪt dʌz - bʌt ðɛɹz noʊ jus ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ɪt. wiv hæd bæd stɔɹmz bɪfɔɹ."

"Storm?" Renald asked. "That one on the horizon, you mean? Thulin, it looks bad - burn my bones, but it does - but there's no use running from it. We've had bad storms before."

"nɑt laɪk ðɪs, oʊl fɹɛnd," θulɪn sɛd. "ðɪs eɪn ðə sɔɹɾ ə stɔɹm jə ɪɡnɔɹ."

"Not like this, old friend," Thulin said. "This ain't the sort of storm you ignore."

"θulɪn?" ɹɪnəld æskt. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?"

"Thulin?" Renald asked. "What are you talking about?"

bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ ænsɝ, ɡæænhə kɔl fɹəm ðə wæɡən bɑks. "dɪd jə tɛl ɪm əbaʊt ðə pɑts?"

Before he could answer, Gallanha called from the wagon box. "Did you tell him about the pots?"

"ɑ," θulɪn sɛd. "ɡæænhə pɑlɪʃt ʌp ðət sɛɾ ə kɑpɝ-bɑɾəm pɑts ðət jəɹ waɪf ɔlweɪz laɪkt. ðəɹ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə kɪtʃən teɪbəl, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ oʊeɪn, ɪf ʃi wɑns tə ɡoʊ kleɪm ðɛm." wɪð ðæt, θulɪn nɑɾəd tə ɹɪnəld ən bɪɡæn tə wɔk bæk təwɔɹd ðə wæɡən.

"Ah," Thulin said. "Gallanha polished up that set of copper-bottom pots that your wife always liked. They're sitting on the kitchen table, waiting for Auaine, if she wants to go claim them." With that, Thulin nodded to Renald and began to walk back toward the wagon.

ɹɪnəl sæt, stupfaɪd. θulɪn ɔlweɪz hæd bɪn ə blʌnt wʌn; hi feɪvɝd seɪɪŋ ɪz maɪnd, ðən muvɪŋ ɑn. ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt ɹɪnəld laɪkt əbaʊt hɪm. bʌt ðə smɪθ kəɾ ɔlsoʊ pæs θɹu ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən laɪk ə boʊldɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ θɹu ə flɑk ə ʃip, livɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn deɪzd.

Renald sat, stupefied. Thulin always had been a blunt one; he favored saying his mind, then moving on. That was part of what Renald liked about him. But the smith could also pass through a conversation like a boulder rolling through a flock of sheep, leaving everyone dazed.

ɹɪnəl skɹæmbəld ʌp, livɪŋ ɪz paɪp ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ ən fɑloʊɪŋ θulɪn daʊn ɪndə ðə jɑɹɾ ən tə ðə wæɡən. bɝn ɪt, ɹɪnəl θɔt, ɡlænsɪŋ tə ðə saɪdz, noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðə bɹaʊn ɡɹæs ən dɛd ʃɹʌbz əɡɛn. hid wɝk hɑɹɾ ɑn ðət jɑɹd.

Renald scrambled up, leaving his pipe on the chair and following Thulin down into the yard and to the wagon. Burn it, Renald thought, glancing to the sides, noticing the brown grass and dead shrubs again. He'd worked hard on that yard.

ðə smɪθ wɑz tʃɛkɪŋ ɑn ðə tʃɪkən kɹeɪts taɪd tə ðə saɪdz ə hɪz vihɪkəl. ɹɪnəl kɑɾ ʌp tə hɪm, ɹitʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə hænd, bʌt ɡæænhə dɪstʃɹæktəd hɪm.

The smith was checking on the chicken crates tied to the sides of his vehicle. Renald caught up to him, reaching out a hand, but Gallanha distracted him.

"hɪɹ, ɹɪnəld," ʃi sɛd fɹəm ðə wæɡən bɑks. "teɪk ðiz." ʃi hɛld aʊɾ ə bæskəɾ ʌv ɛɡz, wʌn lɑk ʌv ɡoʊldən hɛɹ stʃɹeɪɪŋ fɹəm əɹ bʌn. ɹɪnəld ɹitʃt oʊvɝ tə teɪk ðə bæskət. "ɡɪv ðiz tə oʊeɪn. aɪ noʊ jəɹ ʃɔɹɾ ɑn tʃɪkənz ɑn əkaʊn ə ðoʊz fɑksəz læs fɔl."

"Here, Renald," she said from the wagon box. "Take these." She held out a basket of eggs, one lock of golden hair straying from her bun. Renald reached over to take the basket. "Give these to Auaine. I know you're short on chickens on account of those foxes last fall."

ɹɪnəl tʊk ðə bæskəɾ ʌv ɛɡz. səm wɝ waɪt, səm wɝ bɹaʊn. "jɛs, bʌt wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ, ɡæænhə?"

Renald took the basket of eggs. Some were white, some were brown. "Yes, but where are you going, Gallanha?"

"nɔɹθ, maɪ fɹɛnd," θulɪn sɛd. hi wɔk pæst, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɹɪnəlz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi ən ɑɹmi ɡæðɝɪŋ, aɪ fɪɡjɝ. ðəl nid smɪθs."

"North, my friend," Thulin said. He walked past, laying a hand on Renald's shoulder. "There will be an army gathering, I figure. They'll need smiths."

"pliz," ɹɪnəl sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð ðə bæskəɾ ʌv ɛɡz. "æt lis teɪk ə fju mɪnəts. oʊeɪn dʒʌs pʊt səm bɹɛɾ ɪn, wʌn ə ðoʊz θɪk hʌni loʊvz ðət jə laɪk. wi kən dɪskʌs ðɪs oʊvɝ ə ɡeɪm ə stoʊnz."

"Please," Renald said, gesturing with the basket of eggs. "At least take a few minutes. Auaine just put some bread in, one of those thick honey loaves that you like. We can discuss this over a game of stones."

θulɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

Thulin hesitated.

"wid bɛɾɝ bi ɑn ðə muv," ɡæænhə sɛd sɔfli. "ðæt stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ."

"We'd better be on the move," Gallanha said softly. "That storm is coming."

θulɪn nɑɾəd, ðən klaɪmd ʌp ɪndə ðə wæɡən. "ju maɪt wɑnə kʌm nɔɹθ tu, ɹɪnəld. ɪf jə du, bɹɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə kæn." hi pɔzd. "jɔɹ ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf wɪð ðə tulz juv hɪɹ tə də səm smɔl mɛɾəlwɝk, soʊ teɪk jəɹ bɛst saɪθz ən tɝn əm ɪndə pɑlɹmz. jəɹ tu bɛst saɪθz; naʊ doʊnt ɡoʊ skɪmpɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɪð ɛniθɪŋ ðæts ə sɛkən bɛst əɹ ə θɝd bɛst. ɡɛt jəɹ bɛst, kəz ɪts ðə wɛpən jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə juz."

Thulin nodded, then climbed up into the wagon. "You might want to come north too, Renald. If you do, bring everything you can." He paused. "You're good enough with the tools you have here to do some small metalwork, so take your best scythes and turn them into polearms. Your two best scythes; now don't go skimping around with anything that's a second best or a third best. Get your best, because it's the weapon you're going to use."

ɹɪnəl fɹaʊnd. "haʊ dʒju noʊ ðət ðəɹ wɪl bi ən ɑɹmi? θulɪn, bɝn mi, ɪm noʊ soʊlʒɝ!"

Renald frowned. "How do you know that there will be an army? Thulin, burn me, I'm no soldier!"

θulɪn kəntɪnjuɾ əz ɪf i hædn hɝd ðə kɑmɛns. "wɪð ə pɑlɹm jə kən pʊl sʌmbɑɾi ɔf ʌv ə hɔɹs ən stæb ðɛm. ænd, əz aɪ θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt, meɪbi jə kən teɪk ðə θɝd bɛst ən meɪk jɝsɛlf ə kʌpəl ə sɔɹdz."

Thulin continued as if he hadn't heard the comments. "With a polearm you can pull somebody off of a horse and stab them. And, as I think about it, maybe you can take the third best and make yourself a couple of swords."

"wʌt də aɪ noʊ əbaʊt meɪkɪŋ ə sɔɹd? əɹ əbaʊt juzɪŋ ə sɔɹd, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ?"

"What do I know about making a sword? Or about using a sword, for that matter?"

"ju kən lɝn," θulɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ nɔɹθ. "ɛvɹiwʌn wɪl bi niɾəd, ɹɪnəld. ɛvɹiwʌn.

"You can learn," Thulin said, turning north. "Everyone will be needed, Renald. Everyone.

ðəɹ kʌmɪŋ fəɹ ʌs." hi ɡlæns bæk ət ɹɪnəld. "ə sɔɹd ɹɪli ɪzən ɔl ðət tʌf tə meɪk. jə teɪk ə saɪð bleɪɾ ən stʃɹeɪɾən ɪɾ aʊt, ðən jə faɪn jɝsɛlf ə pis ʌv wʊd tə ækt əz ə ɡɑɹd, tə kip ði ɛnəmiz bleɪd fɹəm slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ən kʌɾɪŋ jəɹ hænd. moʊsli jəl dʒʌs bi juzɪŋ θɪŋz ðət juv ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɑt."

They're coming for us." He glanced back at Renald. "A sword really isn't all that tough to make. You take a scythe blade and straighten it out, then you find yourself a piece of wood to act as a guard, to keep the enemy's blade from sliding down and cutting your hand. Mostly you'll just be using things that you've already got."

ɹɪnəl blɪŋkt. hi stɑpt æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz, bʌɾ i kʊdn stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ ðɛm. ðeɪ bʌntʃt ʌp ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz bɹeɪn laɪk kæɾəl ɔl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ə sɪŋɡəl ɡeɪt.

Renald blinked. He stopped asking questions, but he couldn't stop thinking them. They bunched up inside his brain like cattle all trying to force their way through a single gate.

"bɹɪŋ ɔl jəɹ stɑk, ɹɪnəld," θulɪn sɛd. "jul iɾ əm - əɹ jəɹ mɛn wɪl iɾ əm - ən jəl wɑn ðə mɪlk. ən ɪf jə doʊnt, ðən ðɛɹəl bi mɛn jə kən tʃɹeɪd wɪð fəɹ bif əɹ mʌɾən.

"Bring all your stock, Renald," Thulin said. "You'll eat them - or your men will eat them - and you'll want the milk. And if you don't, then there'll be men you can trade with for beef or mutton.

fud wɪl bi skɛɹs, wʌt wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ spɔɪlɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ ən ðə wɪntɝ stɔɹz hævɪŋ ɹʌn loʊ.

Food will be scarce, what with everything spoiling so much and the winter stores having run low.

bɹɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ juv ɡɑt. dʒɹaɪd binz, dʒɹaɪd fɹut, ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

Bring everything you've got. Dried beans, dried fruit, everything."

ɹɪnəld lin bæk əɡɛns ðə ɡeɪt tə hɪz jɑɹd. hi fɛlt wik ən lɪmp. faɪnəli, hi fɔɹst aʊt dʒʌst wʌn kwɛstʃən. "waɪ?"

Renald leaned back against the gate to his yard. He felt weak and limp. Finally, he forced out just one question. "Why?"

θulɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə wæɡən, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɹɪnəlz ʃoʊldɝ əɡɛn.

Thulin hesitated, then stepped away from the wagon, laying a hand on Renald's shoulder again.

"aɪm sɑɹi tə bi soʊ əbɹʌpt. aɪ . . . wɛl, jə noʊ haʊ aɪm wɪð wɝdz, ɹɪnəld. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt ðət stɔɹm ɪz. bʌɾ aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz. aɪv nɛvɝ hɛld ə sɔɹd, bʌt maɪ fɑðɝ fɔɾ ɪn ði il wɔɹ. ɪm ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ. ən ðət stɔɹm minz ði ɛn ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ɹɪnəld. wi nid tə bi ðəɹ wən ɪɾ ɝaɪvz." hi stɑpt, ðən tɝn ən lʊk tə ðə nɔɹθ, wɑtʃɪŋ ðoʊz bɪldɪŋ klaʊdz əz ə fɑɹmhæn maɪt wɑtʃ ə pɔɪzənəs sneɪk i faʊn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə fild. "laɪt pɹəzɝv ʌs, maɪ fɹɛnd. wi nid tə bi ðɛɹ."

"I'm sorry to be so abrupt. I . . . well, you know how I am with words, Renald. I don't know what that storm is. But I know what it means. I've never held a sword, but my father fought in the Aiel War. I'm a Borderlander. And that storm means the end is coming, Renald. We need to be there when it arrives." He stopped, then turned and looked to the north, watching those building clouds as a farmhand might watch a poisonous snake he found in the middle of the field. "Light preserve us, my friend. We need to be there."

ən wɪð ðæt, hi ɹimuvd ɪz hæn ən klaɪm bæk ɪndə ðə wæɡən. ɹɪnəld wɑtʃt əm iz ɔf, nʌdʒɪŋ ði ɑksən ɪndə moʊʃən, hɛɾɪŋ nɔɹθ. ɹɪnəld wɑtʃt fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, filɪŋ nʌm.

And with that, he removed his hand and climbed back into the wagon. Renald watched them ease off, nudging the oxen into motion, heading north. Renald watched for a long time, feeling numb.

ðə dɪstən θʌndɝ kɹækt, laɪk ðə saʊn ʌv ə wɪp, smækɪŋ əɡɛns ðə hɪlz.

The distant thunder cracked, like the sound of a whip, smacking against the hills.

ðə dɔɹ tə ðə fɑɹmhaʊs oʊpən ən ʃʌt. oʊeɪn keɪm aʊt tə hɪm, ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɪn ə bʌn. ɪt hæd bɪn ðət kʌlɝ fəɹ jɪɹz naʊ; ʃid ɡɹeɪɾ ɝli, ən ɹɪnəl hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn fɑn ə ðə kʌlɝ.

The door to the farmhouse opened and shut. Auaine came out to him, gray hair in a bun. It had been that color for years now; she'd grayed early, and Renald had always been fond of the color.

sɪlvɝ, mɔɹ ðən ɡɹeɪ. laɪk ðə klaʊdz.

Silver, more than gray. Like the clouds.

"wɑz ðət θulɪn?" oʊeɪn æskt, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə dɪstənt wæɡən θɹoʊ ʌp dʌst. ə sɪŋɡəl blæk tʃɪkən fɛðɝ blu əkɹɔs ðə ɹoʊdweɪ.

"Was that Thulin?" Auaine asked, watching the distant wagon throw up dust. A single black chicken feather blew across the roadway.

"jɛs."

"Yes."

"æn i dɪdn steɪ, ivən tə tʃæt?"

"And he didn't stay, even to chat?"

ɹɪnəld ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

Renald shook his head.

"oʊ, bʌt ɡæænhə sɛn ɛɡz!" ʃi tʊk ðə bæskəɾ ən bɪɡæn tə tʃɹænsfɝ ði ɛɡz ɪndə hɝ eɪpɹən tə kæɹi ðɛm ɪnsaɪd. "ʃiz sətʃ ə dɪɹ. liv ðə bæskət ðəɹ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd; aɪm ʃʊɹ ʃɪl sɛn sʌmwʌn fəɹ ɪt."

"Oh, but Gallanha sent eggs!" She took the basket and began to transfer the eggs into her apron to carry them inside. "She's such a dear. Leave the basket there on the ground; I'm sure she'll send someone for it."

ɹɪnəl dʒʌst stɛɹd nɔɹθwɝd.

Renald just stared northward.

"ɹɪnəld?" oʊeɪn æskt. "wʌts ɡɑɾən ɪndə ju, jə oʊl stʌmp?"

"Renald?" Auaine asked. "What's gotten into you, you old stump?"

"ʃi pɑlɪʃt ʌp əɹ pɑts fəɹ ju," hi sɛd. "ðə wʌnz wɪð ðə kɑpɝ bɑɾəmz. ðəɹ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ kɪtʃən teɪbəl. ðəɹ jʊɹz ɪf jə wɑn ðɛm."

"She polished up her pots for you," he said. "The ones with the copper bottoms. They're sitting on her kitchen table. They're yours if you want them."

oʊeɪn fɛl saɪlənt. ðən i hɝɾ ə ʃɑɹp saʊn ə kɹækɪŋ, ən i lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi hæd lɛɾ əɹ eɪpɹən ɡɹoʊ slæk, ən ði ɛɡz wɝ slɪpɪŋ fɹi, plɑpɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən kɹækɪŋ.

Auaine fell silent. Then he heard a sharp sound of cracking, and he looked over his shoulder. She had let her apron grow slack, and the eggs were slipping free, plopping to the ground and cracking.

ɪn ə vɛɹi kɑm vɔɪs, oʊeɪn æskt, "dɪd ʃi seɪ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls?"

In a very calm voice, Auaine asked, "Did she say anything else?"

hi skɹætʃt ɪz hɛd, wɪtʃ hædn mʌtʃ hɛɹ lɛf tə spik ʌv. "ʃi sɛd ðə stɔɹm wɑz kʌmɪŋ ən ðeɪ hæd tə hɛd nɔɹθ. θulɪn sɛd wi ʃəd ɡoʊ tu."

He scratched his head, which hadn't much hair left to speak of. "She said the storm was coming and they had to head north. Thulin said we should go too."

ðeɪ stʊd fəɹ ənʌðɝ moʊmənt. oʊeɪn pʊld ʌp ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ eɪpɹən, pɹəzɝvɪŋ ðə mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ði ɛɡz. ʃi dɪdn spɛɹ ə ɡlæns fəɹ ðoʊz ðət hæd fɔlən. ʃi wɑz dʒʌst stɛɹɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd.

They stood for another moment. Auaine pulled up the edge of her apron, preserving the majority of the eggs. She didn't spare a glance for those that had fallen. She was just staring northward.

ɹɪnəl tɝnd. ðə stɔɹm hæd dʒʌmp fɔɹwɝɾ əɡɛn. ən ɪt sim tə hæv ɡɹoʊn dɑɹkɝ sʌmhaʊ.

Renald turned. The storm had jumped forward again. And it seemed to have grown darker somehow.

"aɪ θɪŋk wi ɔt tə lɪsən tə ðɛm, ɹɪnəld," oʊeɪn sɛd. "aɪl . . . əl ɡoʊ fɪks ʌp wʌt wɪl nid tə bɹɪŋ wɪð əs fɹəm ðə haʊs. jə kən ɡoʊ ɝaʊn bæk ən ɡæðɝ ðə mɛn. dɪd ðeɪ seɪ haʊ lɔŋ wɪl bi ɡɔn?"

"I think we ought to listen to them, Renald," Auaine said. "I'll . . . I'll go fix up what we'll need to bring with us from the house. You can go around back and gather the men. Did they say how long we'll be gone?"

"noʊ," hi sɛd. "ðeɪ dɪdn ivən ɹɪli seɪ waɪ. dʒʌs ðət wi nid tə ɡoʊ nɔɹθ fəɹ ðə stɔɹm.

"No," he said. "They didn't even really say why. Just that we need to go north for the storm.

ən . . . ðət ðɪs ɪz ði ɛnd."

And . . . that this is the end."

oʊeɪn ɪnheɪld ʃɑɹpli. "wɛl, jə dʒʌst ɡɛt ðə mɛn ɹɛɾi. əl teɪk kɛɹ ə ðə haʊs."

Auaine inhaled sharply. "Well, you just get the men ready. I'll take care of the house."

ʃi bʌsəld ɪnsaɪd, ən ɹɪnəl fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə stɔɹm. hi ɹaʊndəd ðə haʊs ən ɛntɝd ðə bɑɹnjɑɹd, kɔlɪŋ ðə fɑɹmhænz təɡɛðɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ə staʊt lɑt, ɡʊd mɛn, ɔl ə ðɛm.

She bustled inside, and Renald forced himself to turn away from the storm. He rounded the house and entered the barnyard, calling the farmhands together. They were a stout lot, good men, all of them.

hɪz oʊn sʌnz hæd sɔt ðɛɹ fɔɹtʃənz ɛlswɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪz sɪks wɝkɝz wɝ nɪɹli əz kloʊs tə hɪm əz sʌnz. mɝk, fəvɪɾən, ɹɪnɪn, vɛʃɝ ən æɾəməd ɡæðɝd ɹaʊnd. stɪl filɪŋ deɪzd, ɹɪnəl sɛn tu tə ɡæðɝ ʌp ði ænəməlz, tu mɔɹ tə pæk wʌt ɡɹeɪn ən pɹəvɪʒənz ðeɪ hæd lɛft fɹəm ðə wɪntɝ ən ðə faɪnəl mæn ɔf tə fɛtʃ ɡɛlɛni, hu hæd ɡɔn ɪndə ðə vɪlədʒ fəɹ səm nu sid, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ðə plæntɪŋ hæd ɡɔn bæɾ ɑn əkaʊn ə ðɛɹ stɔɹz.

His own sons had sought their fortunes elsewhere, but his six workers were nearly as close to him as sons. Merk, Favidan, Rinnin, Veshir and Adamad gathered round. Still feeling dazed, Renald sent two to gather up the animals, two more to pack what grain and provisions they had left from the winter and the final man off to fetch Geleni, who had gone into the village for some new seed, just in case the planting had gone bad on account of their stores.

ðə faɪv mɛn skæɾɝd. ɹɪnəl stʊɾ ɪn ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən wɛn ɪndə ðə bɑɹn tə fɛtʃ ɪz laɪtweɪt fɔɹdʒ ən pʊl ɪɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə sʌnlaɪt. ɪt wɑzn dʒʌst ən ænvəl, bʌɾ ə fʊl, kɑmpæk fɔɹdʒ, meɪd fəɹ muvɪŋ. hi hæɾ ɪɾ ɑn ɹoʊlɝz; jə kʊdnt wɝk ə fɔɹdʒ ɪn ə bɑɹn. ɔl ðət dʌs kəd teɪk faɪɝ. hi hiv ðə hændəlz, wilɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt tə ði ælkoʊv sɛɾ ɔf tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə jɑɹd, bɪl fɹəm ɡʊd bɹɪks, wɛɹ i kəd də maɪnɝ ɹɪpɛɹz wən i niɾəd tə.

The five men scattered. Renald stood in the farmyard for a moment, then went into the barn to fetch his lightweight forge and pull it out into the sunlight. It wasn't just an anvil, but a full, compact forge, made for moving. He had it on rollers; you couldn't work a forge in a barn. All that dust could take fire. He heaved the handles, wheeling it out to the alcove set off to the side of the yard, built from good bricks, where he could do minor repairs when he needed to.

ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ, hi hæd ðə faɪɝ stoʊkt. hi wɑzn əz skɪld əz θulɪn, bʌt hid lɝn fɹəm ɪz fɑðɝ ðət biɪŋ eɪbəl tə hændəl ə lɪɾəl ə jəɹ oʊn fɔɹdʒwɝk meɪɾ ə bɪɡ dɪfɝəns. səmtaɪmz, jə kʊdn skwɑndɝ ði aʊɝz ɪt wəd teɪk tə ɡoʊ tə taʊn ən bæk dʒʌs tə fɪks ə bɹoʊkən hɪnʒ.

An hour later, he had the fire stoked. He wasn't as skilled as Thulin, but he'd learned from his father that being able to handle a little of your own forgework made a big difference. Sometimes, you couldn't squander the hours it would take to go to town and back just to fix a broken hinge.

ðə klaʊdz wɝ stɪl ðɛɹ. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk əɾ əm əz i lɛf ðə fɔɹdʒ ən hɛɾəd ɪndə ðə bɑɹn. ðoʊz klaʊdz wɝ laɪk aɪz, pipɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

The clouds were still there. He tried not to look at them as he left the forge and headed into the barn. Those clouds were like eyes, peeping over his shoulder.

ɪnsaɪd ðə bɑɹn, laɪt spɹɪŋkəl daʊn θɹu kɹæks ɪn ðə wɔl, fɔlɪŋ ɑn dʌst ən heɪ. hid bɪl ðə stʃɹʌktʃɝ hɪmsɛlf səm twɛnti-faɪv jɪɹz bæk. hi kɛpt plænɪŋ tə ɹipleɪs səm ə ðoʊz wɔɹpt ɹufɪŋ plæŋks, bʌt naʊ ðəɹ wʊdn bi taɪm.

Inside the barn, light sprinkled down through cracks in the wall, falling on dust and hay. He'd built the structure himself some twenty-five years back. He kept planning to replace some of those warped roofing planks, but now there wouldn't be time.

ət ðə tul wɔl, hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz θɝd-bɛst saɪð, bʌt stɑpt. teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi tʊk ðə bɛst saɪð ɔf ðə wɔl ɪnstɛd. hi wɔk bæk aʊt tə ðə fɔɹdʒ ən nɑk ðə hæft ɔf ðə saɪð.

At the tool wall, he reached for his third-best scythe, but stopped. Taking a deep breath, he took the best scythe off the wall instead. He walked back out to the forge and knocked the haft off the scythe.

əz i tɔs ðə wʊɾ əsaɪd, vɛʃɝ - ɛldəst ə hɪz fɑɹmhænz - əpɹoʊtʃt, pʊlɪŋ ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡoʊts. wən vɛʃɝ sɔ ðə saɪð bleɪɾ ɑn ðə fɔɹdʒ, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu dɑɹk. hi taɪd ðə ɡoʊts tə ə poʊst, ðən tʃɹɑɾəd oʊvɝ tə ɹɪnəld, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

As he tossed the wood aside, Veshir - eldest of his farmhands - approached, pulling a pair of goats. When Veshir saw the scythe blade on the forge, his expression grew dark. He tied the goats to a post, then trotted over to Renald, but said nothing.

haʊ tə meɪk ə pɑlɹm? θulɪn hæd sɛd ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊd fəɹ jæŋkɪŋ ə mæn ɔf ɪz hɔɹs. wɛl, hi wəɾ əv tə ɹipleɪs ðə snæθ wɪð ə lɔŋɡɝ stʃɹeɪt ʃæft ʌv æʃwʊd. ðə flæŋʒd ɛn ə ðə ʃæft wəɾ ɪkstɛn bɪɑn ðə hil ə ðə bleɪd, ʃeɪpt ɪndə ə kɹud spɪɹpɔɪn ən klæd wɪð ə pis ə tɪn fəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ. ən ðən i wəɾ əv tə hit ðə bleɪɾ ən bæŋ ɔf ðə toʊ əbaʊt hæfweɪ, meɪkɪŋ ə hʊk ðət kəd tʌɡ ə mæn ɔf ɪz hɔɹs ən meɪbi kʌɾ ɪm ət ðə seɪm taɪm. hi slɪd ðə bleɪɾ ɪndə ðə bɝnɪŋ koʊlz tə hiɾ ɪt, ðən bɪɡæn tə taɪ ɑn ɪz eɪpɹən.

How to make a polearm? Thulin had said they were good for yanking a man off his horse. Well, he would have to replace the snath with a longer straight shaft of ashwood. The flanged end of the shaft would extend beyond the heel of the blade, shaped into a crude spearpoint and clad with a piece of tin for strength. And then he would have to heat the blade and bang off the toe about halfway, making a hook that could tug a man off his horse and maybe cut him at the same time. He slid the blade into the burning coals to heat it, then began to tie on his apron.

vɛʃɝ stʊd ðəɹ fəɹ ə mɪnəɾ əɹ soʊ, wɑtʃɪŋ. faɪnəli, hi stɛpt ʌp, teɪkɪŋ ɹɪnəl baɪ ði ɑɹm.

Veshir stood there for a minute or so, watching. Finally, he stepped up, taking Renald by the arm.

"ɹɪnəld, wʌɾ ɑɹ wi duɪŋ?"

"Renald, what are we doing?"

ɹɪnəld ʃʊk ɪz ɑɹm fɹi. "wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ nɔɹθ. ðə stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ ən wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ nɔɹθ."

Renald shook his arm free. "We're going north. The storm is coming and we're going north."

"wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ nɔɹθ fəɹ dʒʌst ə stɔɹm? ɪts ɪnsænəɾi!"

"We're going north for just a storm? It's insanity!"

ɪt wɑz nɪɹli ðə seɪm θɪŋ ɹɪnəl hæd sɛd tə θulɪn. dɪstən θʌndɝ saʊndəd.

It was nearly the same thing Renald had said to Thulin. Distant thunder sounded.

θulɪn wɑz ɹaɪt. ðə kɹɑps . . . ðə skaɪz . . . ðə fud ɡoʊɪŋ bæd wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ. ivən bɪfɔɹ hid spoʊkən tə θulɪn, ɹɪnəl hæd noʊn. dip wɪðɪn, hid noʊn. ðɪs stɔɹm wəd nɑt pæs oʊvɝhɛd ðən vænɪʃ. ɪt hæd tə bi kənfɹʌntəd.

Thulin was right. The crops . . . the skies . . . the food going bad without warning. Even before he'd spoken to Thulin, Renald had known. Deep within, he'd known. This storm would not pass overhead then vanish. It had to be confronted.

"vɛʃɝ," ɹɪnəl sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə hɪz wɝk, "juv bɪn ə hæn ɑn ðɪs fɑɹm fəɹ . . . wʌt, fɪftin jɪɹz naʊ? jəɹ ðə fɝs mæn aɪ haɪɝd. haʊ wɛl əv aɪ tʃɹiɾəd jə ən jʊɹz?"

"Veshir," Renald said, turning back to his work, "you've been a hand on this farm for . . . what, fifteen years now? You're the first man I hired. How well have I treated you and yours?"

"juv dʌn mi wɛl," vɛʃɝ sɛd. "bʌt bɝn mi, ɹɪnəld, juv nɛvɝ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv ðə fɑɹm bɪfɔɹ! ðiz kɹɑps, ðəl wɪðɝ tə dʌst ɪf wi liv ðɛm. ðɪs eɪnt noʊ sʌðɝnɝ wɛtfɑɹm.

"You've done me well," Veshir said. "But burn me, Renald, you've never decided to leave the farm before! These crops, they'll wither to dust if we leave them. This ain't no southerner wetfarm.

haʊ kən wi dʒʌst ɡoʊ ɔf?"

How can we just go off?"

"bɪkɔz," ɹɪnəl sɛd, "ɪf wi doʊn liv, ðən ɪt woʊn mæɾɝ ɪf wi plæntəɾ əɹ nɑt."

"Because," Renald said, "if we don't leave, then it won't matter if we planted or not."

vɛʃɝ fɹaʊnd.

Veshir frowned.

"sʌn," ɹɪnəl sɛd, "jul də əz aɪ seɪ, ən ðæts ɔl wɪl əv ʌv ɪt. ɡoʊ fɪnɪʃ ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə stɑk."

"Son," Renald said, "you'll do as I say, and that's all we'll have of it. Go finish gathering the stock."

vɛʃɝ stɔkt əweɪ, bʌɾ i dɪɾ əz i wɑz toʊld. hi wɑz ə ɡʊd mæn, ɪf hɑthɛɾəd.

Veshir stalked away, but he did as he was told. He was a good man, if hotheaded.

ɹɪnəl pʊl ðə bleɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə hit, ðə mɛɾəl ɡloʊɪŋ waɪt. hi leɪɾ ɪɾ əɡɛns ðə smɔl ænvəl ən bɪɡæn tə biɾ ɑn ðə nɑbi sɛkʃən wɛɹ hil mɛt bɪɹd, flæɾənɪŋ ɪt. ðə saʊn ə hɪz hæmɝ ɑn ðə mɛɾəl sim laʊɾɝ ðən ɪt ʃəɾ əv bɪn. ɪt ɹæŋ laɪk ðə pilɪŋ θʌndɝ, ən ðə saʊnz blɛndəd. əz ɪf itʃ biɾ ə hɪz hæmɝ wɑz ɪtsɛlf ə pis ə ðə stɔɹm.

Renald pulled the blade out of the heat, the metal glowing white. He laid it against the small anvil and began to beat on the knobby section where heel met beard, flattening it. The sound of his hammer on the metal seemed louder than it should have been. It rang like the pealing thunder, and the sounds blended. As if each beat of his hammer was itself a piece of the storm.

əz i wɝkt, ðə pilz sim tə fɔɹm wɝdz. laɪk sʌmbɑɾi mʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd.

As he worked, the peals seemed to form words. Like somebody muttering in the back of his head.

ðə seɪm fɹeɪz oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ.

The same phrase over and over.

ðə stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ. ðə stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ. . . .

The storm is coming. The storm is coming. . . .

hi kɛpt ɑn paʊndɪŋ, kipɪŋ ði ɛdʒ ɑn ðə saɪð, bʌt stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ðə bleɪɾ ən meɪkɪŋ ə hʊk ət ði ɛnd. hi stɪl dɪdnt noʊ waɪ. bʌɾ ɪt dɪdn mæɾɝ.

He kept on pounding, keeping the edge on the scythe, but straightening the blade and making a hook at the end. He still didn't know why. But it didn't matter.

ðə stɔɹm wɑz kʌmɪŋ ən i hæd tə bi ɹɛɾi.

The storm was coming and he had to be ready.

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə boʊlɪɡd soʊlʒɝz taɪ teɪnɛɹəz blæŋkət-ɹæp bɑɾi əkɹɔs ə sæɾəl, fælɛnʒɹ fɔt ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə bɪɡɪn wipɪŋ əɡɛn, ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə vɑmət. ʃi wɑz sinjɝ, ən hæd tə meɪnteɪn səm kəmpoʊʒɝ ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəd ðə fɔɹ ʌðɝ sɝvaɪvɪŋ sʌldəm tə də soʊ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl hɝsɛlf ʃi hæd sin wɝs, bæɾəlz wɛɹ mɔɹ ðən ə sɪŋɡəl sʌldəm hæd daɪd, mɔɹ ðən wʌn deɪmeɪn. ðət bɹɔɾ əɹ tu nɪɹ θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪɡzækli haʊ teɪnɛɹə ən əɹ mɪɹi mɛt ðɛɹ dɛθs, ðoʊ, ən əɹ maɪnd ʃaɪd fɹəm ɪt.

Watching the bowlegged soldiers tie Tanera's blanket-wrapped body across a saddle, Falendre fought the desire to begin weeping again, the desire to vomit. She was senior, and had to maintain some composure if she expected the four other surviving sul'dam to do so. She tried to tell herself she had seen worse, battles where more than a single sul'dam had died, more than one damane. That brought her too near thinking of exactly how Tanera and her Miri met their deaths, though, and her mind shied from it.

hʌɾəlɪŋ baɪ hɝ saɪd, nɛntʃi wɪmpɝɾ əz fælɛnʒɹ stʃɹoʊk ðə deɪmeɪnz hɛɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə sɛn suðɪŋ filɪŋz θɹu ði æɾəm. ðəɾ ɔfən sim tə wɝk, bʌt nɑt soʊ wɛl tədeɪ. hɝ oʊn ɪmoʊʃənz wɝ tu ɹɔɪld. ɪf oʊnli ʃi kəd fɝɡɛt ðət ðə deɪmeɪn wɑz ʃildɪd, ən baɪ hum. baɪ wʌt. nɛntʃi wɪmpɝɾ əɡɛn.

Huddling by her side, Nenci whimpered as Falendre stroked the damane's head and tried to send soothing feelings through the a'dam. That often seemed to work, but not so well today. Her own emotions were too roiled. If only she could forget that the damane was shielded, and by whom. By what. Nenci whimpered again.

"ju wɪl dɪlɪvɝ ðə mɛsədʒ əz aɪ dɝɛktəd ju?" ə mæn sɛd bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"You will deliver the message as I directed you?" a man said behind her.

noʊ, nɑt dʒʌst ɛni mæn. ðə saʊn ə hɪz vɔɪs stɝd ðə pul ʌv æsəɾ ɪn əɹ bɛli. ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf tɝn tə feɪs hɪm, meɪd hɝsɛlf mit ðoʊz koʊld, hɑɹɾ aɪz. ðeɪ tʃeɪnʒd wɪð ði æŋɡəl ə hɪz hɛd, naʊ blu, naʊ ɡɹeɪ, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz laɪk pɑlɪʃt dʒɛmstoʊnz. ʃi hæd noʊn mɛni hɑɹd mɛn, bʌt hæd ʃi ɛvɝ noʊn wʌn hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə luz ə hæn ən moʊməns leɪɾɝ teɪk ɪɾ əz ɪf i hæd lɔst ə ɡlʌv? ʃi baʊd fɔɹməli, twɪtʃɪŋ ði æɾəm soʊ ðət nɛntʃi dɪd ðə seɪm. soʊ fɑɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn tʃɹiɾəd wɛl fəɹ pɹɪznɝz ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, ivən tə biɪŋ ɡɪvən wɑʃwɔɾɝ, ən səpoʊzədli ðeɪ wəd nɑt ɹɪmeɪn pɹɪznɝz mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ. jɛt wɪð ðɪs mæn, hu kəd seɪ wʌt maɪt meɪk ðət tʃeɪnʒ? ðə pɹɑməs ə fɹiɾəm maɪt bi pɑɹɾ ə səm skim.

No, not just any man. The sound of his voice stirred the pool of acid in her belly. She made herself turn to face him, made herself meet those cold, hard eyes. They changed with the angle of his head, now blue, now gray, but always like polished gemstones. She had known many hard men, but had she ever known one hard enough to lose a hand and moments later take it as if he had lost a glove? She bowed formally, twitching the a'dam so that Nenci did the same. So far they had been treated well for prisoners under the circumstances, even to being given washwater, and supposedly they would not remain prisoners much longer. Yet with this man, who could say what might make that change? The promise of freedom might be part of some scheme.

"aɪ wɪl dɪlɪvɝ jəɹ mɛsədʒ wɪð ðə kɛɹ ɪt ɹikwaɪɝz," ʃi bɪɡæn, ðən stʌmbəld oʊvɝ əɹ tʌŋ.

"I will deliver your message with the care it requires," she began, then stumbled over her tongue.

wʌɾ ɑnɝɪfɪk dɪd ʃi jus fəɹ hɪm? "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ʃi fɪnɪʃt hɝidli. ðə wɝdz dʒɹaɪɾ əɹ tʌŋ, bʌɾ i nɑɾəd, soʊ ɪt mʌst əv səfaɪst.

What honorific did she use for him? "My Lord Dragon," she finished hurriedly. The words dried her tongue, but he nodded, so it must have sufficed.

wʌn ə ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn əpɪɹd θɹu ðəɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ, ə jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə lɔŋ bɹeɪd. ʃi wɔɹ ɪnʌf dʒuəlɹi fəɹ wʌn ə ðə blʌd, ən ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ə ɹɛd dɑɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɝ fɔɹhɛd. "haʊ lɔŋ dʒju min tə steɪ hɪɹ, ɹænd?" ʃi dɪmændəɾ əz ɪf ðə hɑɹd- aɪd jʌŋ mæn wɝ ə sɝvən ɹæðɝ ðən u hi wɑz. "haʊ kloʊz tə ɛbu dɑɹ ɑɹ wi hɪɹ? ðə pleɪs ɪz fʊl ə sintʃæn, jə noʊ, ən ðeɪ pɹɑbli flaɪ ɹeɪkən ɔl ɝaʊn ɪt."

One of the marath'damane appeared through that impossible hole in the air, a young woman with her hair in a long braid. She wore enough jewelry for one of the Blood, and of all things, a red dot in the middle of her forehead. "How long do you mean to stay here, Rand?" she demanded as if the hard- eyed young man were a servant rather than who he was. "How close to Ebou Dar are we here? The place is full of Seanchan, you know, and they probably fly raken all around it."

"dɪd kædzueɪn sɛn jə tə æsk ðæt?" hi sɛd, ən əɹ tʃiks kʌlɝd feɪnli. "nɑt mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, nɪneɪiv. ə fju mɪnəts."

"Did Cadsuane send you to ask that?" he said, and her cheeks colored faintly. "Not much longer, Nynaeve. A few minutes."

ðə jʌŋ wʊmən ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ɡeɪz tə ði ʌðɝ sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn, ɔl teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ lɛd fɹəm fælɛnʒɹ, pɹitɛndɪŋ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm, ən ɪspɛʃli noʊ mɛn ɪn blæk koʊts. ði ʌðɝz hæd stʃɹeɪɾənd ðɛmsɛlvz əz bɛs ðeɪ kʊd. sɝjə hæd wɑʃt ðə blʌd fɹəm əɹ feɪs, ən fɹəm əɹ tɑbiz feɪs, ən mɑliən hæd taɪd lɑɹdʒ kɑmpɹɛsəz ɑn əm ðət meɪɾ əm əpɪɹ tə bi wɛɹɪŋ ɑd hæts. tʃiɹ hæd mænədʒ tə klin ɔf moʊst ə ðə vɑmət ʃi hæd spɪl daʊn ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ dʒɹɛs.

The young woman shifted her gaze to the other sul'dam and damane, all taking their lead from Falendre, pretending there were no marath'damane watching them, and especially no men in black coats. The others had straightened themselves as best they could. Surya had washed the blood from her face, and from her Tabi's face, and Malian had tied large compresses on them that made them appear to be wearing odd hats. Ciar had managed to clean off most of the vomit she had spilled down the front of her dress.

"aɪ stɪl θɪŋk aɪ ʃəd hil ðɛm," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. "hɪts tə ðə hɛd kən kɑz ɑd θɪŋz ðət doʊn kʌm ɑn ɹaɪɾ əweɪ."

"I still think I should Heal them," Nynaeve said abruptly. "Hits to the head can cause odd things that don't come on right away."

sɝjə, hɝ feɪs hɑɹɾənɪŋ, muv tɑbi bɪhaɪn əɹ əz ɪf tə pɹətɛk ðə deɪmeɪn. əz ɪf ʃi kʊd.

Surya, her face hardening, moved Tabi behind her as if to protect the damane. As if she could.

tɑbiz peɪl aɪz hæd waɪɾənd ɪn hɔɹɝ.

Tabi's pale eyes had widened in horror.

fælɛnʒɹ ɹeɪzd ə pliɾɪŋ hæn təwɔɹd ðə tɔl jʌŋ mæn. təwɔɹd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ɪt simd. "pliz. ðəl ɹəsiv mɛɾəkəl eɪɾ əz sun əz wi ɹitʃ ɛbu dɑɹ."

Falendre raised a pleading hand toward the tall young man. Toward the Dragon Reborn, it seemed. "Please. They will receive medical aid as soon as we reach Ebou Dar."

"ɡɪv oʊvɝ, nɪneɪiv," ðə jʌŋ mæn sɛd. "ɪf ðeɪ doʊnt wɑn hilɪŋ, ðeɪ doʊnt wɑn ɪt." ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn skaʊld ət hɪm, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ əɹ nʌkəlz tɝnd waɪt. hi tɝn ɪz oʊn ətɛnʃən bæk tə fælɛnʒɹ. "ðə ɹoʊd tə ɛbu dɑɹ laɪz əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝ ist ə hɪɹ. jə kən ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi baɪ naɪtfɔl ɪf jə pɹɛs. ðə ʃilz ɑn ðə deɪmeɪn wɪl ɪvæpɝeɪɾ ɪn əbaʊt hæf ən aʊɝ. ɪz ðət ɹaɪt fəɹ ðə seɪaɪdɑɹ-woʊvən ʃilz, nɪneɪiv?" ðə wʊmən skaʊld əɾ ɪm ɪn saɪləns. "ɪz ðət ɹaɪt, nɪneɪiv?"

"Give over, Nynaeve," the young man said. "If they don't want Healing, they don't want it." The marath'damane scowled at him, gripping her braid so hard that her knuckles turned white. He turned his own attention back to Falendre. "The road to Ebou Dar lies about an hour east of here. You can reach the city by nightfall if you press. The shields on the damane will evaporate in about half an hour. Is that right for the saidar-woven shields, Nynaeve?" The woman scowled at him in silence. "Is that right, Nynaeve?"

"hæf ən aʊɝ," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd faɪnəli. "bʌt nʌn ə ðɪs ɪz ɹaɪt, ɹænd ælθɹ. sɛndɪŋ ðoʊz deɪmeɪn bæk. ɪɾ ɪzən ɹaɪt, ən jə noʊ ɪt."

"Half an hour," she replied finally. "But none of this is right, Rand al'Thor. Sending those damane back. It isn't right, and you know it."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hɪz aɪz wɝ ivən koʊldɝ. nɑt hɑɹɾɝ. ðət wʊɾə bɪn ɪmpɑsəbəl. bʌt fəɹ ðət lɔŋ moʊmənt, ðeɪ sim tə hoʊl kævɝnz ʌv aɪs. "ɹaɪt wɑz izi tə faɪnd wən ɔl aɪ hæd tə kɛɹ fəɹ wɑz ə fju ʃip," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "naʊədeɪz, səmtaɪmz ɪts hɑɹɾɝ tə kʌm baɪ." tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, hi ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs. "lɑɡən, ɡɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn bæk θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. jɛs, jɛs, mɛɹaɪs. aɪm nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəmæn ju. ɪf jəl dn tə dʒɔɪn ʌs, ðoʊ? ɪɾəl bi kloʊzɪŋ sun."

For a moment, his eyes were even colder. Not harder. That would have been impossible. But for that long moment, they seemed to hold caverns of ice. "Right was easy to find when all I had to care for was a few sheep," he said quietly. "Nowadays, sometimes it's harder to come by." Turning away, he raised his voice. "Logain, get everyone back through the gateway. Yes, yes, Merise. I'm not trying to command you. If you'll deign to join us, though? It will be closing soon."

mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, ðə wʌnz u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bɪɡæn faɪlɪŋ θɹu ðət mæɾ oʊpənɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, əz dɪd ðə blæk-koʊɾəd mɛn, ði æʃəmən, ɔl mɪŋɡəlɪŋ wɪð ðə hʊk-noʊz soʊlʒɝz. sɛvɹəl ə ðoʊz fɪnɪʃt taɪɪŋ teɪnɛɹə tə ðə sæɾəl ə ðə hɔɹs. ðə bists hæd bɪn pɹəvaɪɾəd baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. haʊ ɑd, ðəɾ i ʃəd ɡɪv əm ɡɪfs æftɝ wʌt hæd hæpənd.

Marath'damane, the ones who called themselves Aes Sedai, began filing through that mad opening in the air, as did the black-coated men, the Asha'man, all mingling with the hook-nosed soldiers. Several of those finished tying Tanera to the saddle of the horse. The beasts had been provided by the Dragon Reborn. How odd, that he should give them gifts after what had happened.

ðə hɑɹd-aɪd jʌŋ mæn tɝn bæk tə hɝ. "ɹɪpit jəɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz."

The hard-eyed young man turned back to her. "Repeat your instructions."

"aɪ æm tə ɹɪtɝn tə ɛbu dɑɹ wɪð ə mɛsədʒ fəɹ əɹ liɾɝz ðɛɹ."

"I am to return to Ebou Dar with a message for our leaders there."

"ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz," ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn sɛd stɝnli. "ju wɪl dɪlɪvɝ maɪ mɛsədʒ tə hɝ."

"The Daughter of the Nine Moons," the Dragon Reborn said sternly. "You will deliver my message to her."

fælɛnʒɹ stʌmbəld. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ɛni weɪ wɝði tə spik tə wʌn ə ðə blʌd, lɛɾ əloʊn ðə haɪ leɪɾi, dɔɾɝ ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ! bʌt ðɪs mænz ɪkspɹɛʃən əlaʊd noʊ ɑɹɡjəmənt. fælɛnʒɹ wəd faɪn ə weɪ. "aɪ wɪl dɪlɪvɝ jəɹ mɛsədʒ tə hɝ," fælɛnʒɹ kəntɪnjud. "aɪ wɪl tɛl əɹ ðət . . . ðət jə bɛɹ əɹ noʊ mæləs fəɹ ðɪs ətæk, ən ðət jə dɪzaɪɝ ə miɾɪŋ."

Falendre stumbled. She was not in any way worthy to speak to one of the Blood, let alone the High Lady, daughter of the Empress, might she live forever! But this man's expression allowed no argument. Falendre would find a way. "I will deliver your message to her," Falendre continued. "I will tell her that . . . that you bear her no malice for this attack, and that you desire a meeting."

"aɪ stɪl dɪzaɪɝ wʌn," ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn sɛd.

"I still desire one," the Dragon Reborn said.

əz fɑɹ əz fælɛnʒɹ nu, ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz hæd nɛvɝ noʊn əbaʊt ði ɝɪdʒənəl miɾɪŋ. ɪt hæd bɪn ɝeɪnʒd ɪn sikɹət baɪ ænæθ. ən ðət wɑz waɪ fælɛnʒɹ nu fəɹ sɝɾən ðət ðɪs mæn mʌs bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. fəɹ oʊnli ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf kəd feɪs wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ən nɑɾ oʊnli sɝvaɪv, bʌt kʌm aʊt ðə vɪktɝ.

As far as Falendre knew, the Daughter of the Nine Moons had never known about the original meeting. It had been arranged in secret by Anath. And that was why Falendre knew for certain that this man must be the Dragon Reborn. For only the Dragon Reborn himself could face one of the Forsaken and not only survive, but come out the victor.

wɑz ðət ɹɪli wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn? wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən? fælɛnʒɹz maɪn ɹild ət ðə kɑnsɛpt.

Was that really what she had been? One of the Forsaken? Falendre's mind reeled at the concept.

ɪmpɑsəbəl. ən jɛt, hɪɹ wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪf i lɪvd, ɪf i wɔk ðə lænd, ðən ðə fɔɹseɪkən wʊd, tu. ʃi wɑz mʌɾəld, hɝ θɔts ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn sɝkəlz, ʃi nu. ʃi bɑɾəld ʌp əɹ tɛɹɝ - ʃi wəd dil wɪð ðət leɪɾɝ. ʃi niɾəd tə bi ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl.

Impossible. And yet, here was the Dragon Reborn. If he lived, if he walked the land, then the Forsaken would, too. She was muddled, her thoughts going in circles, she knew. She bottled up her terror - she would deal with that later. She needed to be in control.

ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə mit ðoʊz fɹoʊzən dʒɛmstoʊnz ðɪs mæn hæd fəɹ aɪz. ʃi hæd tə pɹəzɝv səm dɪɡnəɾi ɪf oʊnli tə ɹiəʃʊɹ ðə fɔɹ ʌðɝ sɝvaɪvɪŋ sʌldəm. ən ðə deɪmeɪn, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪf ðə sʌldəm lɔs kəmpoʊʒɝ əɡɛn, ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ hoʊp fəɹ ðə deɪmeɪn.

She forced herself to meet those frozen gemstones this man had for eyes. She had to preserve some dignity if only to reassure the four other surviving sul'dam. And the damane, of course. If the sul'dam lost composure again, there would be no hope for the damane.

"aɪ wɪl tɛl hɝ," fælɛnʒɹ sɛd, mænɪdʒɪŋ tə kip əɹ vɔɪs ivən, "ðæt jə stɪl dɪzaɪɝ ə miɾɪŋ wɪð hɝ. ðət jə bɪliv ðəɹ mʌs bi pis bɪtwin əɹ pipəlz. ən aɪm tə tɛl əɹ ðət leɪɾi ænæθ wɑz . . . wɑz wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən."

"I will tell her," Falendre said, managing to keep her voice even, "that you still desire a meeting with her. That you believe there must be peace between our peoples. And I am to tell her that Lady Anath was . . . was one of the Forsaken."

tə ðə saɪd, ʃi sɔ səm ə ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn pʊʃ ænæθ θɹu ðə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ, meɪnteɪnɪŋ ə steɪtli bɛɹɪŋ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ kæptɪvəɾi. ʃi ɔlweɪz hæd tʃɹaɪd tə dɑməneɪɾ əbʌv əɹ steɪʃən. kəd ʃi ɹɪli bi wʌt ðɪs mæn sɛd ʃi wɑz?

To the side, she saw some of the marath'damane push Anath through the hole in the air, maintaining a stately bearing despite her captivity. She always had tried to dominate above her station. Could she really be what this man said she was?

haʊ wɑz fælɛnʒɹ tə feɪs ðə dɝsʌldəm ən ɪkspleɪn ðɪs tʃɹædʒəɾi, ðɪs tɛɹəbəl mɛs? ʃi ɪtʃt tə bi əweɪ fɹəm ɪt, tə faɪn sʌmpleɪs tə haɪd.

How was Falendre to face the der'sul'dam and explain this tragedy, this terrible mess? She itched to be away from it, to find someplace to hide.

"wi mʌst əv pis," ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn sɛd. "aɪ wɪl si ɪt hæpən. tɛl jəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ðət ʃi kən faɪn mi ɪn ɑɹæd dumən; əl kwɛl ðə bæɾəl əɡɛns jəɹ fɔɹsɪz ðɛɹ. lɛɾ əɹ noʊ ðəɾ aɪ ɡɪv ðɪs əz ə saɪn ʌv ɡʊd feɪθ, dʒʌst əz aɪ ɹilis jə aʊɾ ʌv ɡʊd feɪθ. ɪts noʊ ʃeɪm tə bi mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd baɪ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli nɑt . . . ðət kɹitʃɝ. ɪn ə weɪ, aɪ ɹɛs mɔɹ izəli, naʊ. aɪ wɝid ðət wʌn ə ðɛm wʊɾə ɪnfɪltʃɹeɪɾɪd ðə sintʃæn noʊbɪləɾi. aɪ ʃʊɾə ɡɛs ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi sɛmɝhɪdʒ. ʃi ɔlweɪz pɹəfɝɾ ə tʃælənʒ."

"We must have peace," the Dragon Reborn said. "I will see it happen. Tell your mistress that she can find me in Arad Doman; I will quell the battle against your forces there. Let her know that I give this as a sign of good faith, just as I release you out of good faith. It is no shame to be manipulated by one of the Forsaken, particularly not . . . that creature. In a way, I rest more easily, now. I worried that one of them would have infiltrated the Seanchan nobility. I should have guessed that it would be Semirhage. She always preferred a challenge."

hi spoʊk ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɪð ən ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl sɛns ə fəmɪljɛɹəɾi, ən ɪt ɡeɪv fælɛnʒɹ tʃɪlz.

He spoke of the Forsaken with an incredible sense of familiarity, and it gave Falendre chills.

hi ɡlænst ət hɝ. "ju meɪ ɡoʊ," hi sɛd, ðən wɔkt oʊvɝ ən pæs θɹu ðə ɹɪp ɪn ði ɛɹ.

He glanced at her. "You may go," he said, then walked over and passed through the rip in the air.

wʌt ʃi wəd ɡɪv tə hæv ðət tʃɹævlɪŋ tʃɹɪk fəɹ nɛntʃi. ðə læst ə ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn pæs θɹu ðə hoʊl, ən ɪt kloʊzd, livɪŋ fælɛnʒɹ ən ði ʌðɝz əloʊn. ðeɪ wɝ ə sɑɹi ɡɹup. tælhə wɑz stɪl kɹaɪɪŋ, ən mɑliən lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə sɪk ʌp. sɛvɹəl ə ði ʌðɝz hæd hæd blʌɾid feɪsəz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɑʃt, ən feɪn ɹɛd smɪɹz ən fleɪks ə kɹʌstɪd blʌd stɪl mɑɹd ðɛɹ skɪn. fælɛnʒɹ wɑz ɡlæd ʃi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə əvɔɪɾ æksɛptɪŋ hilɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm. ʃi hæd sin wʌn ə ðoʊz mɛn hilɪŋ mɛmbɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz pɑɹɾi. hu nu wʌt teɪn ɪt wəd liv ɑn ə pɝsən tə bi bɪniθ ðoʊz kɝʌp hænz?

What she would give to have that traveling trick for Nenci. The last of the marath'damane passed through the hole, and it closed, leaving Falendre and the others alone. They were a sorry group. Talha was still crying, and Malian looked ready to sick up. Several of the others had had bloodied faces before they washed, and faint red smears and flakes of crusted blood still marred their skin. Falendre was glad she had been able to avoid accepting Healing for them. She had seen one of those men Healing members of the Dragon's party. Who knew what taint it would leave on a person to be beneath those corrupt hands?

"bi stʃɹɔŋ," ʃi kəmændəd ði ʌðɝz, filɪŋ fɑɹ mɔɹ ənsɝɾən ðən ʃi saʊndəd. hi hæɾ æktʃəli  lɛɾ əɹ fɹi! ʃid bɛɹli dɛɹd hoʊp fəɹ ðæt. bɛs tə bi əweɪ sun. vɛɹi sun. ʃi tʃɪid ði ʌðɝz ɑntu ðə hɔɹsəz i hæd ɡɪvən, ən wɪðɪn mɪnəts ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ saʊθ, təwɔɹɾ ɛbu dɑɹ, itʃ sʌldəm ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð əɹ kəmpænjən deɪmeɪn əɾ əɹ saɪd.

"Be strong," she commanded the others, feeling far more uncertain than she sounded. He had actually let her free! She'd barely dared hope for that. Best to be away soon. Very soon. She chivvied the others onto the horses he had given, and within minutes they were riding south, toward Ebou Dar, each sul'dam riding with her companion damane at her side.

ði ɪvɛns ə ðɪs deɪ kəd min hævɪŋ əɹ deɪmeɪn stʃɹɪp fɹəm hɝ, biɪŋ fɔɹbɪɾən tə hoʊl ði æɾəm ɛvɝ əɡɛn. wɪð ænæθ ɡɔn, pʌnɪʃmənt wəd bi dɪmændəɾ ə sʌmwʌn. wʌt wəd haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ seɪ? deɪmeɪn dɛd, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪnsʌltɪd.

The events of this day could mean having her damane stripped from her, being forbidden to hold the a'dam ever again. With Anath gone, punishment would be demanded of someone. What would High Lady Suroth say? Damane dead, the Dragon Reborn insulted.

ʃʊɹli luzɪŋ æksɛs tə ði æɾəm wɑz ðə wɝs ðət kəd hæpən tə hɝ. ðeɪ wʊdn meɪk wʌn sətʃ əz fælɛnʒɹ dækoʊvæl, wəd ðeɪ? ðə θɔt meɪd ðə baɪl twɪst ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɝ əɡɛn.

Surely losing access to the a'dam was the worst that could happen to her. They wouldn't make one such as Falendre da'covale, would they? The thought made the bile twist inside of her again.

ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɪkspleɪn ði ɪvɛns ə ðɪs deɪ vɛɹi kɛɹfəli. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ ʃi kəd pɹizɛn ðiz mæɾɝz ɪn ə weɪ ðət wəd seɪv əɹ laɪf.

She would have to explain the events of this day very carefully. There had to be a way she could present these matters in a way that would save her life.

ʃi hæd ɡɪvən əɹ wɝd tə ðə dʒɹæɡən tə spik dɝɛkli tə ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. ən ʃi wʊd. bʌt ʃi maɪt nɑt də soʊ ɪmiɾiətli. kɛɹfəl kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən wəɾ əv tə bi ɡɪvən. vɛɹi kɛɹfəl kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən.

She had given her word to the Dragon to speak directly to the Daughter of the Nine Moons. And she would. But she might not do so immediately. Careful consideration would have to be given. Very careful consideration.

ʃi lin ɪn kloʊs tə hɝ hɔɹsəz nɛk, nʌdʒɪŋ əɹ maʊn fɔɹwɝd, əhɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝz. ðət weɪ, ðeɪ wʊdn si ðə tɪɹz ə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, peɪn ən tɛɹɝ ɪn əɹ aɪz.

She leaned in close to her horse's neck, nudging her mount forward, ahead of the others. That way, they wouldn't see the tears of frustration, pain and terror in her eyes.

taɪli kɪɝɡən, lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl ə ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi, sæɾ əɹ hɔɹs ətɑp ə fɔɹəstəd hɪltɑp, lʊkɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd. sətʃ ə dɪfɹən pleɪs ðɪs lænd wɑz. hɝ hoʊmlænd, mɛɹæm kæʃɹ, wɑz ə dʒɹaɪ aɪlən ɑn ðə vɛɹi saʊθistɝn tɪp ə sintʃæn. ðə lʌmə tʃɹiz ðəɹ wɝ stʃɹeɪt, taʊɝɪŋ mɑnstɝz, wɪð fɹɑnz spɹaʊɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə tɑp laɪk ðə hɛɹ kɹɛst ʌv ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə haɪ blʌd.

Tylee Khirgan, Lieutenant-General of the Ever Victorious Army, sat her horse atop a forested hilltop, looking northward. Such a different place this land was. Her homeland, Maram Kashor, was a dry island on the very southeastern tip of Seanchan. The lumma trees there were straight, towering monsters, with fronds sprouting from the top like the hair crest of a member of the High Blood.

ðə θɪŋz ðət pæs fəɹ tʃɹiz ɪn ðɪs lænd wɝ nɑɹld, twɪstɪŋ, bɹæntʃɪŋ ʃɹʌbz baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən. ðɛɹ lɪmz wɝ laɪk ðə fɪŋɡɝz ʌv oʊl soʊlʒɝz, ɡɔn ɑɹθɹɪɾɪk fɹəm jɪɹz hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹd. wʌt hæd ðə loʊkəlz kɔl ðiz plæns? bɹʌʃwʊd tʃɹiz? soʊ ɑd. tə θɪŋk ðət səm ə hɝ ænsɛstɝz maɪɾ əv kʌm fɹəm ðɪs pleɪs, tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ tə sintʃæn.

The things that passed for trees in this land were gnarled, twisting, branching shrubs by comparison. Their limbs were like the fingers of old soldiers, gone arthritic from years holding the sword. What had the locals called these plants? Brushwood trees? So odd. To think that some of her ancestors might have come from this place, traveling with Luthair Paendrag to Seanchan.

hɝ ɑɹmi mɑɹtʃt daʊn ðə ɹoʊd bɪloʊ, θɹoʊɪŋ dʌst ɪndə ði ɛɹ. θaʊzənz əpɑn θaʊzənz ə mɛn. fjuɝ ðən ʃid hæd bɪfɔɹ, bʌt nɑt baɪ mɛni. ɪt hæd bɪn tu wiks sɪns əɹ faɪt wɪð ði il, wɛɹ pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹəz plæn hæd wɝkt ɪmpɹɛsɪvli. faɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ə mæn laɪk ɪm wɑz ɔlweɪz ə bɪɾɝswit ɪkspɪɹiəns. swit fəɹ ðə ʃɪɹ dʒinjəs ʌv ɪt. bɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə wɝi ðət wʌn deɪ, ðeɪ wəd feɪs itʃ ʌðɝ ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild. taɪli wɑz nɑt wʌn u ɛndʒɔɪɾ ə tʃælənʒ ɪn ə faɪt.

Her army marched down the road below, throwing dust into the air. Thousands upon thousands of men. Fewer than she'd had before, but not by many. It had been two weeks since her fight with the Aiel, where Perrin Aybara's plan had worked impressively. Fighting alongside a man like him was always a bittersweet experience. Sweet for the sheer genius of it. Bitter for the worry that one day, they would face each other on the battlefield. Tylee was not one who enjoyed a challenge in a fight.

ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz pɹəfɝd tə wɪn stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt.

She'd always preferred to win straight out.

səm dʒɛnɝəlz sɛd ðət nɛvɝ stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ mɛnt nɛvɝ biɪŋ fɔɹs tə ɪmpɹuv. taɪli fɪɡjɝd ðət ʃi ən əɹ mɛn wəd də ðɛɹ ɪmpɹuvɪŋ ɑn ðə pɹæktəs fild, ən liv ðə stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə hɝ ɛnəmiz.

Some generals said that never struggling meant never being forced to improve. Tylee figured that she and her men would do their improving on the practice field, and leave the struggling to her enemies.

ʃi wəd nɑt laɪk tə feɪs pɛɹɪn. noʊ, ʃi wəd nɑt. ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz ʃi wɑz fɑn ə hɪm.

She would not like to face Perrin. No, she would not. And not just because she was fond of him.

sloʊ hʊfbits saʊndəɾ ɑn ði ɝθ. ʃi ɡlæns tə ðə saɪɾ əz mɪʃimə ɹoʊɾ ɪz hɔɹs, ə peɪl ɡɛldɪŋ, ʌp nɛks tə hɝz. hi hæɾ ɪz hɛlm taɪd tə hɪz sæɾəl, ən ɪz skɑɹd feɪs wɑz θɔtfəl. ðeɪ wɝ ə pɛɹ, ðə tu ʌv ðɛm. taɪliz oʊn feɪs bɔɹ ɪts ʃɛɹ ʌv oʊl skɑɹz.

Slow hoofbeats sounded on the earth. She glanced to the side as Mishima rode his horse, a pale gelding, up next to hers. He had his helm tied to his saddle, and his scarred face was thoughtful. They were a pair, the two of them. Tylee's own face bore its share of old scars.

mɪʃimə səluɾəd hɝ, mɔɹ ɹɪspɛkfəl naʊ ðət taɪli hæd bɪn ɹeɪz tə ðə blʌd. ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ mɛsədʒ, dɪlɪvɝd baɪ ɹeɪkən, hæd bɪn ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd wʌn. ɪt wɑz ən ɑnɝ, ən wʌn ʃi stɪl wɑzn əkʌstəm tə.

Mishima saluted her, more respectful now that Tylee had been raised to the Blood. That particular message, delivered by raken, had been an unexpected one. It was an honor, and one she still wasn't accustomed to.

"stɪl mʌlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə bæɾəl?" mɪʃimə æskt.

"Still mulling over the battle?" Mishima asked.

"aɪ æm," taɪli sɛd. tu wiks, ən stɪl ɪt dɑməneɪɾəd əɹ maɪnd. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk?"

"I am," Tylee said. Two weeks, and still it dominated her mind. "What do you think?"

"ʌv eɪbɑɹə, jə min?" mɪʃimə æskt. hi stɪl spoʊk tə hɝ laɪk ə fɹɛnd, ivən ɪf i kɛp hɪmsɛlf fɹəm miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz. "hi ɪz ə ɡʊd soʊlʒɝ. pɝhæps tu foʊkəst, tu dʒɹɪvən. bʌt sɑləd."

"Of Aybara, you mean?" Mishima asked. He still spoke to her like a friend, even if he kept himself from meeting her eyes. "He is a good soldier. Perhaps too focused, too driven. But solid."

"jɛs," taɪli sɛd, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ðə wɝld ɪz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, mɪʃimə. ɪn weɪz wi kænɑɾ æntɪsəpeɪt. fɝst eɪbɑɹə, ən ðən ði ɑɾətiz."

"Yes," Tylee said, then shook her head. "The world is changing, Mishima. In ways we cannot anticipate. First Aybara, and then the oddities."

mɪʃimə nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. "ðə mɛn doʊnt wɑnə spik ə ðɛm."

Mishima nodded thoughtfully. "The men don't want to speak of them."

"ði ɪvɛns əv hæpən tu ɔfən tə bi ðə wɝk ə dɪluʒən," taɪli sɛd. "ðə skaʊts ɑɹ siɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ."

"The events have happened too often to be the work of delusion," Tylee said. "The scouts are seeing something."

"mɛn doʊn dʒʌs vænɪʃ," mɪʃimə sɛd. "ju θɪŋk ɪts ðə wʌn paʊɝ?"

"Men don't just vanish," Mishima said. "You think it's the One Power?"

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz," ʃi sɛd. ʃi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹiz ɝaʊn hɝ. səm tʃɹiz ʃid pæst ɝliɝ hæd bɪɡʌn tə sɛn aʊt spɹɪŋ ɡɹoʊθ, bʌt nɑɾ ə wʌn ə ðiz hæd dʌn soʊ. ðeɪ lʊk skɛləɾəl, ðoʊ ði ɛɹ wɑz wɔɹm ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪt tə bi plæntɪŋ sizən ɔlɹɛɾi. "du ðeɪv tʃɹiz laɪk ðɪs ɪn hæləmək?"

"I do not know what it is," she said. She glanced over the trees around her. Some trees she'd passed earlier had begun to send out spring growth, but not a one of these had done so. They looked skeletal, though the air was warm enough for it to be planting season already. "Do they have trees like this in Halamak?"

"nɑɾ ɪɡzækli laɪk ðɛm," mɪʃimə sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪv sin ðɛɹ laɪk bɪfɔɹ."

"Not exactly like them," Mishima said. "But I've seen their like before."

"ʃʊd ðeɪv bʌddɪd baɪ naʊ?"

"Should they have budded by now?"

hi ʃɹʌɡd. "ɪm ə soʊlʒɝ, dʒɛnɝəl taɪli."

He shrugged. "I'm a soldier, General Tylee."

"aɪ hædnt noʊɾəst," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

"I hadn't noticed," she said dryly.

hi ɡɹʌntɪd.
