"aɪ min ðəɾ aɪ doʊn peɪ ətɛnʃən tə tʃɹiz. tʃɹiz doʊn blid. pɝhæps ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv bʌddɪd, bʌt pɝhæps nɑt. fju θɪŋz meɪk sɛns ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən. tʃɹiz ðət doʊn bʌɾ ɪn spɹɪŋ, ðæts dʒʌst ənʌðɝ ɑɾəti. bɛɾɝ ðət ðən mɔɹ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn æktɪŋ laɪk ðeɪ wɝ ə ðə blʌd, ɛvɹiwʌn boʊɪŋ ən skɹeɪpɪŋ tə ðɛm." hi ʃʌɾɝəd vɪzəbli.

He grunted. "I mean that I don't pay attention to trees. Trees don't bleed. Perhaps they should have budded, but perhaps not. Few things make sense on this side of the ocean. Trees that don't bud in spring, that's just another oddity. Better that than more marath'damane acting like they were of the Blood, everyone bowing and scraping to them." He shuddered visibly.

taɪli nɑɾəd, bʌt ʃi dɪdnt ʃɛɹ ɪz ɹɪvʌlʃən. nɑt kəmplitli. ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt tə θɪŋk ə pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə ən ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ, lɛɾ əloʊn ɪz æʃəmən. ən ʃi dɪdnt noʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ əbaʊt tʃɹiz ðən mɪʃimə. bʌɾ ɪt fɛl tə hɝ ðət ðeɪ ʃʊɾə stɑɹɾəd tə bʌd. ən ðoʊz mɛn ðə skaʊts kɛp siɪŋ ɪn ðə filz, haʊ kəd ðeɪ vænɪʃ soʊ kwɪkli, ivən wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ?

Tylee nodded, but she didn't share his revulsion. Not completely. She wasn't certain what to think of Perrin Aybara and his Aes Sedai, let alone his Asha'man. And she didn't know much more about trees than Mishima. But it felt to her that they should have started to bud. And those men the scouts kept seeing in the fields, how could they vanish so quickly, even with the One Power?

ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ hæɾ oʊpən ʌp wʌn ə ðɛɹ pæks ə tʃɹævəl ɹæʃənz tədeɪ ən faʊn oʊnli dʌst.

The quartermaster had opened up one of their packs of travel rations today and found only dust.

taɪli wʊɾə stɑɹɾəd ə sɝtʃ fəɹ ə θif əɹ ə pɹæŋkstɝ ɪf ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ hædn ɪnsɪstəd ðət hid tʃɛk ðət pæk dʒʌs moʊməns bɪfɔɹ. kɑɹm wɑz ə sɑləd mæn; hid bɪn əɹ kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ fəɹ jɪɹz. hi dɪd nɑt meɪk mɪsteɪks.

Tylee would have started a search for a thief or a prankster if the quartermaster hadn't insisted that he'd checked that pack just moments before. Karm was a solid man; he'd been her quartermaster for years. He did not make mistakes.

ɹɑɾɪŋ fud wɑz soʊ kɑmən hɪɹ. kɑɹm bleɪm ðə hiɾ ə ðɪs stʃɹeɪnʒ lænd. bʌt tʃɹævəl ɹæʃənz kʊdn ɹɑɾ əɹ spɔɪl, ət lis nɑt ðɪs ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbli. ði oʊmənz wɝ ɔl bæd, ðiz deɪz. ɝliɝ tədeɪ, ʃid sin tu dɛd ɹæts laɪɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, wʌn wɪð ə teɪl ɪn ðə maʊθ ə ði ʌðɝ. ɪt wɑz ðə wɝst oʊmən ʃiɾ ɛvɝ sin ɪn əɹ laɪf, ən ɪt stɪl tʃɪld əɹ tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt.

Rotting food was so common here. Karm blamed the heat of this strange land. But travel rations couldn't rot or spoil, at least not this unpredictably. The omens were all bad, these days. Earlier today, she'd seen two dead rats lying on their backs, one with a tail in the mouth of the other. It was the worst omen she'd ever seen in her life, and it still chilled her to think of it.

sʌmθɪŋ wɑz hæpənɪŋ. pɛɹɪn hædn bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə spik ʌv ɪt mʌtʃ, bʌt ʃi sɔ ə weɪɾ əpɑn hɪm. hi nu mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən i hæd spoʊkən.

Something was happening. Perrin hadn't been willing to speak of it much, but she saw a weight upon him. He knew much more than he had spoken.

wi kæn əfɔɹd tə bi faɪɾɪŋ ðiz pipəl, ʃi θɔt. ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪbɛljəs θɔt, wʌn ʃi wʊdn spik tə mɪʃimə. ʃi dɪdn dɛɹ pɑndɝ ɪt. ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðət ðɪs læn bi ɹikleɪmd. sjuɹɔθ ən ɡælɡən wɝ ði ɛmpaɪɝz tʃoʊzən liɾɝz ɪn ðə vɛntʃɝ, əntɪl ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz ɹɪvil hɝsɛlf. waɪl taɪli kʊdnt noʊ ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑnz θɔts, sjuɹɔθ ən ɡælɡən wɝ junaɪɾəd ɪn ðɛɹ dɪzaɪɝ tə si ðɪs læn səbdud. ɪt wɑz pɹæktəkli ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðeɪ dɪɾ əɡɹi əpɑn.

We can't afford to be fighting these people, she thought. It was a rebellious thought, one she wouldn't speak to Mishima. She didn't dare ponder it. The Empress, might she live forever, had ordered that this land be reclaimed. Suroth and Galgan were the Empire's chosen leaders in the venture, until the Daughter of the Nine Moons revealed herself. While Tylee couldn't know the High Lady Tuon's thoughts, Suroth and Galgan were united in their desire to see this land subdued. It was practically the only thing they did agree upon.

nʌn ə ðɛm wəd lɪsən tə sədʒɛstʃənz ðət ðeɪ ʃəd bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ælaɪz əmʌŋ ðə pipəl ə ðɪs lænd, ɹæðɝ ðən ɛnəmiz. θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt wɑz kloʊs tə tʃɹizən. ɪnsəbɔɹɾəneɪʃən, ət list. ʃi saɪɾ ən tɝn tə mɪʃimə, pɹipɛɹd tə ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ tə bɪɡɪn skaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ ə pleɪs tə kæmp fəɹ ðə naɪt.

None of them would listen to suggestions that they should be looking for allies among the people of this land, rather than enemies. Thinking about it was close to treason. Insubordination, at least. She sighed and turned to Mishima, prepared to give the order to begin scouting for a place to camp for the night.

ʃi fɹoʊz. mɪʃimə hæɾ ən æɹoʊ θɹu hɪz nɛk, ə wɪkəd, bɑɹb θɪŋ. ʃi hædn hɝɾ ɪt stʃɹaɪk. hi mɛɾ əɹ aɪz, stʌnd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə spik ən oʊnli lɛɾɪŋ aʊt blʌd. hi slɪd fɹəm ðə sæɾəl ən kəlæpst ɪn ə hip əz sʌmθɪŋ ɪnɔɹməs tʃɑɹdʒ θɹu ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ bɪsaɪd taɪli, kɹækɪŋ nɑɹl bɹæntʃəz, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ət hɝ. ʃi bɛɹli hæd taɪm tə pʊl fɹi hɝ sɔɹɾ ən ʃaʊt bɪfɔɹ dʌstɝ - ə ɡʊd, sɑləd wɔɹhɔɹs ðət hæd nɛvɝ feɪld əɹ ɪn bæɾəl - ɹɪɹɾ ɪn pænɪk, tɔsɪŋ əɹ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

She froze. Mishima had an arrow through his neck, a wicked, barbed thing. She hadn't heard it strike. He met her eyes, stunned, trying to speak and only letting out blood. He slid from the saddle and collapsed in a heap as something enormous charged through the underbrush beside Tylee, cracking gnarled branches, throwing itself at her. She barely had time to pull free her sword and shout before Duster - a good, solid warhorse that had never failed her in battle - reared in panic, tossing her to the ground.

ðət pɹɑbli seɪvd əɹ laɪf, əz əɹ ətækɝ swʌŋ ə θɪk-bleɪɾɪd sɔɹd, kʌɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə sæɾəl wɛɹ taɪli hæd bɪn. ʃi skɹæmbəl tə hɝ fit, ɑɹmɝ klæŋkɪŋ, ən skɹim ði əlɝt. "tə ɑɹmz!

That probably saved her life, as her attacker swung a thick-bladed sword, cutting into the saddle where Tylee had been. She scrambled to her feet, armor clanking, and screamed the alert. "To arms!

ətæk!"

Attack!"

hɝ vɔɪs dʒɔɪn hʌnʒɹədz u meɪd ðə seɪm kɔl ət vɝtʃuəli ðə seɪm taɪm. mɛn skɹimd.

Her voice joined hundreds who made the same call at virtually the same time. Men screamed.

hɔɹsəz wɪnid.

Horses whinnied.

ən æmbʊʃ, ʃi θɔt, ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ bleɪd. ən wi wɔkt ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ɪt! wɛɹ ɑɹ ðə skaʊts?

An ambush, she thought, raising her blade. And we walked right into it! Where are the scouts?

wʌt hæpənd? ʃi lɔntʃt hɝsɛlf ət ðə mæn u hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɝ. hi spʌn, snɔɹɾɪŋ.

What happened? She launched herself at the man who had tried to kill her. He spun, snorting.

ən fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ʃi sɔ dʒʌst wʌɾ i wɑz. nɑt kwaɪɾ ə mæn - ɪnstɛd, səm kɹitʃɝ wɪð twɪstəd fitʃɝz, ðə hɛd kʌvɝɾ ɪn kɔɹs bɹaʊn hɛɹ, ðə tu-waɪd fɔɹhɛd ɹɪŋkəld wɪð θɪk skɪn. ðoʊz aɪz wɝ dɪstɝbɪŋli hjumən-laɪk, bʌt ðə noʊz bɪloʊ wɑz flæɾənd laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ə bɔɹ ən ðə maʊθ dʒʌɾɪd wɪð tu pɹɑmənən tʌsks. ðə kɹitʃɝ ɹɔɹɾ ət hɝ, spɪɾəl spɹeɪɪŋ fɹəm ɪts nɪɹli hjumən lɪps.

And for the first time, she saw just what he was. Not quite a man - instead, some creature with twisted features, the head covered in coarse brown hair, the too-wide forehead wrinkled with thick skin. Those eyes were disturbingly human-like, but the nose below was flattened like that of a boar and the mouth jutted with two prominent tusks. The creature roared at her, spittle spraying from its nearly human lips.

blʌɾ ə maɪ fɑðɝz fɝɡɑɾən, ʃi θɔt. wʌɾ əv wi stʌmbəld ɪntu? ðə mɑnstɝ wɑz ə naɪtmɛɹ, ɡɪvən ə bɑɾi ən lɛt lus tə kɪl. ɪt wɑz ə θɪŋ ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz dɪsmɪst əz supɝstɪʃən.

Blood of my Fathers Forgotten, she thought. What have we stumbled into? The monster was a nightmare, given a body and let loose to kill. It was a thing she had always dismissed as superstition.

ʃi tʃɑɹdʒ ðə kɹitʃɝ, nɑkɪŋ əsaɪɾ ɪts θɪk sɔɹɾ əz ɪt tʃɹaɪd tə ətæk. ʃi spʌn, fɔlɪŋ ɪndə bit ðə bɹʌʃɪz, ən sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðə bists ɑɹm fɹəm ɪts ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi stʃɹʌk əɡɛn, ən ɪts hɛd fɑloʊd ði ɑɹm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, kʌt fɹi. ɪt stʌmbəld, sʌmhaʊ stɪl wɔkɪŋ θɹi stɛps, bɪfɔɹ kəlæpsɪŋ.

She charged the creature, knocking aside its thick sword as it tried to attack. She spun, falling into Beat the Brushes, and separated the beast's arm from its shoulder. She struck again, and its head followed the arm to the ground, cut free. It stumbled, somehow still walking three steps, before collapsing.

ðə tʃɹiz ɹʌsəld, mɔɹ bɹæntʃəz snæpɪŋ. dʒʌs daʊn fɹəm əɹ hɪlsaɪd, taɪli sɔ ðət hʌnʒɹədz ə ðə kɹitʃɝz hæd bɹoʊkən aʊɾ ə ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ, ətækɪŋ ðə laɪn ə hɝ mɛn nɪɹ ðə mɪɾəl, kɑzɪŋ keɪɑs. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ə ðə mɑnstɝz pɔɹd bɪtwin ðə tʃɹiz.

The trees rustled, more branches snapping. Just down from her hillside, Tylee saw that hundreds of the creatures had broken out of the underbrush, attacking the line of her men near the middle, causing chaos. More and more of the monsters poured between the trees.

haʊ hæd ðɪs hæpənd? haʊ hæd ðiz θɪŋz ɡɑɾən soʊ kloʊs tə ɛbu dɑɹ! ðeɪ wɝ wɛl ɪnsaɪd ðə sintʃæn dɪfɛnsɪv pɝɪməɾɝ, oʊnli ə deɪz mɑɹtʃ fɹəm ðə kæpəɾəl.

How had this happened? How had these things gotten so close to Ebou Dar! They were well inside the Seanchan defensive perimeter, only a day's march from the capital.

taɪli tʃɑɹdʒ daʊn ðə hɪlsaɪd, bɛloʊɪŋ fəɹ əɹ ɑnɝ ɡɑɹɾ əz mɔɹ ə ðə bists ɹɔɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Tylee charged down the hillside, bellowing for her honor guard as more of the beasts roared out of the trees behind her.

ɡɹeɪndəl laʊnʒd ɪn ə stoʊnwɝk ɹum laɪnd wɪð ədɔɹɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən, itʃ wʌn ə pɝfək spɛsəmən, itʃ wʌn wɛɹɪŋ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə ɹoʊb ə daɪəfənəs waɪt klɔθ. ə wɔɹm faɪɝ pleɪɾ ɪn ðə hɑɹθ, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ə faɪn ɹʌɡ ʌv blʌd ɹɛd. ðət ɹʌɡ wɑz woʊvən ɪn ðə dɪzaɪn ə jʌŋ wɪmən ən mɛn ɛntæŋɡəld ɪn weɪz ðət wʊɾə meɪɾ ivən ən ɪkspɪɹiəns kɔɝɾəsən blʌʃ. ði oʊpən wɪndoʊz lɛɾ ɪn æftɝnun laɪt, ðə lɔfti pəzɪʃən ə hɝ pæləs ɡɪvɪŋ ə vju ʌv paɪnz ən ə ʃɪmɝɪŋ leɪk bɪloʊ.

Graendal lounged in a stonework room lined with adoring men and women, each one a perfect specimen, each one wearing little more than a robe of diaphanous white cloth. A warm fire played in the hearth, illuminating a fine rug of blood red. That rug was woven in the design of young women and men entangled in ways that would have made even an experienced courtesan blush. The open windows let in afternoon light, the lofty position of her palace giving a view of pines and a shimmering lake below.

ʃi sɪp switbɹɪsəl dʒus, wɛɹɪŋ ə peɪl blu dʒɹɛs æftɝ ðə dəmɑni kʌt - ʃi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ fɑn ə ðɛɹ fæʃənz, ðoʊ hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ fɪlmi ðən ðə wʌnz ðeɪ wɔɹ. ðiz dəmɑni wɝ tu fɑn ʌv wɪspɝɪŋ wən ɡɹeɪndəl pɹəfɝɾ ə naɪs ʃɑɹp skɹim. ʃi tʊk ənʌðɝ sɪp ə dʒus. wʌɾ ən ɪntɝɛstɪŋli saʊɝ fleɪvɝ ɪt hæd. ɪt wɑz ɪɡzɑɾɪk dʊɹɪŋ ðɪs eɪdʒ, sɪns ðə tʃɹiz naʊ ɡɹu oʊnli ɑn dɪstən aɪlənz.

She sipped sweetbristle juice, wearing a pale blue dress after the Domani cut - she was growing fond of their fashions, though her dress was far more filmy than the ones they wore. These Domani were too fond of whispering when Graendal preferred a nice sharp scream. She took another sip of juice. What an interestingly sour flavor it had. It was exotic during this Age, since the trees now grew only on distant islands.

wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ, ə ɡeɪtweɪ spʌn oʊpən ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum. ʃi kɝst ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ əz wʌn ə hɝ faɪnəs pɹaɪzəz - ə sʌkjəlɪn jʌŋ wʊmən neɪm θʊɝɑsə, ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə dəmɑni mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl - nɪɹli lɔst ən ɑɹm tə ðə θɪŋ. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ lɛɾ ɪn ə swɛltɝɪŋ hit ðət mɑɹd ðə pɝfək mɪks ə tʃɪl maʊntən ɛɹ ən faɪɝpleɪs wɔɹmθ ʃi hæd kʌltəveɪɾəd.

Without warning, a gateway spun open in the center of the room. She cursed under her breath as one of her finest prizes - a succulent young woman named Thurasa, a member of the Domani merchant council - nearly lost an arm to the thing. The gateway let in a sweltering heat that marred the perfect mix of chill mountain air and fireplace warmth she had cultivated.

ɡɹeɪndəl kɛpt əɹ kəmpoʊʒɝ, fɔɹsɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə laʊnʒ bæk ɪn əɹ oʊvɝstʌf vɛlvət tʃɛɹ. ə mɛsənʒɝ ɪn blæk stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðə pɔɹɾəl, ən ʃi nu wʌɾ i wɑntəd bɪfɔɹ i spoʊk. oʊnli mɔɹaɪɾɪn nu wɛɹ tə faɪn hɝ, naʊ ðət sɑmaɪl wɑz dɛd.

Graendal kept her composure, forcing herself to lounge back in her overstuffed velvet chair. A messenger in black strode through the portal, and she knew what he wanted before he spoke. Only Moridin knew where to find her, now that Sammael was dead.

"maɪ leɪɾi, jəɹ pɹɛzəns ɪz ɹikwaɪɝd baɪ - "

"My Lady, your presence is required by - "

"jɛs, jɛs," ʃi sɛd. "stæn stʃɹeɪɾ ən lemi si ju."

"Yes, yes," she said. "Stand straight and let me see you."

ðə juθ stʊd stɪl, dʒʌs tu stɛps ɪndə ðə ɹum. ən maɪ, hi wɑz ətʃɹæktɪv! peɪl ɡoʊldən hɛɹ əz wɑz soʊ ɹɛɹ ɪn mɛni pɑɹts ə ðə wɝld, ɡɹin aɪz ðət ʃɪmɝd laɪk mɔs-ɡɹoʊn pulz, ə laɪð fɪɡjɝ tɔt wɪð dʒʌst ɪnʌf mʌsəl. ɡɹeɪndəl klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ. wɑz mɔɹaɪɾɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɛmpt əɹ baɪ sɛndɪŋ ɪz vɛɹi moʊs pɹɪɾi, əɹ wɑz ðə tʃɔɪs koʊɪnsədɛntəl?

The youth stood still, just two steps into the room. And my, he was attractive! Pale golden hair as was so rare in many parts of the world, green eyes that shimmered like moss-grown pools, a lithe figure taut with just enough muscle. Graendal clicked her tongue. Was Moridin trying to tempt her by sending his very most pretty, or was the choice coincidental?

noʊ. əmʌŋ ðə tʃoʊzən, ðəɹ wɝ noʊ koʊɪnsəɾənsɪz. ɡɹeɪndəl nɪɹli ɹitʃt aʊt wɪð ə wiv ə kəmpʌlʃən tə siz ðə bɔɪ fəɹ hɝsɛlf. haʊɛvɝ, ʃi ɹistʃɹeɪn hɝsɛlf. wʌns ə mæn hæd noʊn ðət lɛvəl ə kəmpʌlʃən, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɹɪkʌvɝ hɪm, ən mɔɹaɪɾɪn maɪt bi æŋɡɝd. ʃi dɪd nid tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪz wɪmz. ðə mæn nɛvɝ hæd bɪn steɪbəl, ivən dʊɹɪŋ ði ɝli jɪɹz. ɪf ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə si hɝsɛlf əz nɛbli sʌmdeɪ, ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt nɑt tə ɹaɪl ɪm əntɪl ɪt wɑz taɪm tə stʃɹaɪk.

No. Among the Chosen, there were no coincidences. Graendal nearly reached out with a weave of Compulsion to seize the boy for herself. However, she restrained herself. Once a man had known that level of Compulsion, there was no way to recover him, and Moridin might be angered. She did need to worry about his whims. The man never had been stable, even during the early years. If she intended to see herself as Nae'blis someday, it was important not to rile him until it was time to strike.

ʃi tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən əweɪ fɹəm ðə mɛsənʒɝ - ɪf ʃi kʊdn əv hɪm, ðən ʃi wɑzn ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɪm - ən lʊk θɹu ði oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ. ʃi heɪɾəd biɪŋ fɔɹs tə mit wɪð wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ tʃoʊzən ɑn ðɛɹ tɝmz. ʃi heɪɾəd livɪŋ əɹ stʃɹɔŋhoʊld ən əɹ pɛts. moʊst ʌv ɔl, ʃi heɪɾəd biɪŋ fɔɹs tə ɡɹɑvəl bɪfɔɹ wʌn u ʃʊɾə bɪn əɹ səbɔɹɾəneɪt.

She turned her attention away from the messenger - if she couldn't have him, then she wasn't interested in him - and looked through the open gateway. She hated being forced to meet with one of the other Chosen on their terms. She hated leaving her stronghold and her pets. Most of all, she hated being forced to grovel before one who should have been her subordinate.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊɾ ɪt. mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɑz nɛbli. fəɹ naʊ. ən ðət mɛnt, heɪɾ ɪɾ əɹ nɑt, ɡɹeɪndəl hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə ænsɝ ɪz sʌmənz. soʊ ʃi sɛɾ əsaɪɾ əɹ dʒɹɪŋk, ðən stʊɾ ən wɔk θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, hɝ daɪəfənəs peɪl blu ɡaʊn ʃɪmɝɪŋ wɪð ɡoʊldən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi.

There was nothing to be done about it. Moridin was Nae'blis. For now. And that meant, hate it or not, Graendal had no choice but to answer his summons. So she set aside her drink, then stood and walked through the gateway, her diaphanous pale blue gown shimmering with golden embroidery.

ɪt wɑz dɪstʃɹæktəŋli hɑɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ʃi ɪmiɾiətli woʊv ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ, kulɪŋ ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi wɑz ɪn ə blæk stoʊn bɪldɪŋ, wɪð ɹʌɾi laɪt kʌmɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz. ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɡlæs ɪn ðɛm. ðət ɹɛɾɪʃ tɪn ɪmplaɪɾ ə sʌnsɛt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɹli mɪdæftɝnun bæk ɪn ɑɹæd dumən. ʃʊɹli ʃi hædn tʃɹævəl ðət fɑɹ, hæd ʃi?

It was distractingly hot on the other side of the gateway. She immediately wove Air and Water, cooling the air around her. She was in a black stone building, with ruddy light coming in the windows. They had no glass in them. That reddish tint implied a sunset, but it was barely midafternoon back in Arad Doman. Surely she hadn't traveled that far, had she?

ðə ɹum wɑz fɝnɪʃt oʊnli wɪð hɑɹd tʃɛɹz ə ðə dipəs blæk wʊd. mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɝɾənli wɑz lækɪŋ ɪn ɪmædʒəneɪʃən leɪtli. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ə blæk ən ɹɛd, ən ɔl foʊkəst ɑn kɪlɪŋ ðoʊz ful bɔɪz fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒ ə ɹænd ælθɹ. wɑz ʃi ði oʊnli wʌn u sɔ ðəɾ ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf wɑz ðə ɹil θɹɛt? waɪ nɑt dʒʌs kɪl ɪm ən bi dʌn wɪð ɪt?

The room was furnished only with hard chairs of the deepest black wood. Moridin certainly was lacking in imagination lately. Everything of black and red, and all focused on killing those fool boys from the village of Rand al'Thor. Was she the only one who saw that al'Thor himself was the real threat? Why not just kill him and be done with it?

ðə moʊst ɑbviəs ænsɝ tə ðət kwɛstʃən - ðət nʌn ə ðɛm soʊ fɑɹ hæd pɹuvən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə dɪfiɾ ɪm - wɑz wʌn ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪ kɑntəmpleɪɾɪŋ.

The most obvious answer to that question - that none of them so far had proven strong enough to defeat him - was one she did not enjoy contemplating.

ʃi wɔk tə ðə wɪndoʊ ən faʊn ðə ɹizən fəɹ ðə ɹʌst-kʌlɝd laɪt. aʊtsaɪd, ðə kleɪlaɪk ɡɹaʊnd wɑz steɪn ɹɛd fɹəm ði aɪɝn ɪn ðə sɔɪl. ʃi wɑz ɑn ðə sɛkən lɛvəl ʌv ə dip blæk taʊɝ, ðə stoʊnz dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪn ðə bɝnɪŋ hiɾ ə ðə skaɪ. vɛɹi lɪɾəl vɛdʒəteɪʃən spɹaʊɾəd aʊtsaɪd, ən ðət wɪtʃ dɪd wɑz spɑɾəd wɪð blæk. soʊ, ɪt wɑz ðə dip nɔɹθistɝn blaɪt. ɪt hæd bɪn səm taɪm sɪns ʃid bɪn hɪɹ. mɔɹaɪɾɪn sim tə hæv loʊkeɪɾəd ə fɔɹtʃɹəs, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz.

She walked to the window and found the reason for the rust-colored light. Outside, the claylike ground was stained red from the iron in the soil. She was on the second level of a deep black tower, the stones drawing in the burning heat of the sky. Very little vegetation sprouted outside, and that which did was spotted with black. So, it was the deep northeastern Blight. It had been some time since she'd been here. Moridin seemed to have located a fortress, of all things.

ə kəlɛkʃən ə ʃɑɾi hʌts stʊɾ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs, ən ə fju pætʃəz ə blaɪtstʃɹeɪn kɹɑps mɑɹk filz ɪn ðə dɪstəns. ðeɪ wɝ pɹɑbli tʃɹaɪɪŋ ə nu stʃɹeɪn, koʊksɪŋ ɪt tə ɡɹoʊ ɪn ði ɛɹiə. pɝhæps sɛvɹəl dɪfɹən kɹɑps; ðət wəɾ ɪkspleɪn ðə pætʃəz. ɡɑɹdz pɹaʊl ði ɛɹiə, wɛɹɪŋ blæk junəfɔɹmz dɪspaɪt ðə hit. soʊlʒɝz wɝ nɛsəsɛɹi tə faɪɾ ɔf ətæks fɹəm ðə vɛɹiəs ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ðəɾ ɪnhæbəɾəd ðə lænz ðɪs dip wɪðɪn ðə blaɪt. ðoʊz kɹitʃɝz oʊbeɪd noʊ mæstɝ seɪv fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hɪmsɛlf. wʌt wɑz mɔɹaɪɾɪn duɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ aʊt hɪɹ?

A collection of shoddy huts stood in the shadow of the fortress, and a few patches of blightstrain crops marked fields in the distance. They were probably trying a new strain, coaxing it to grow in the area. Perhaps several different crops; that would explain the patches. Guards prowled the area, wearing black uniforms despite the heat. Soldiers were necessary to fight off attacks from the various Shadowspawn that inhabited the lands this deep within the Blight. Those creatures obeyed no master save for the Great Lord himself. What was Moridin doing all the way out here?

hɝ spɛkjəleɪʃən wɑz kʌt ʃɔɹɾ əz fʊtstɛps ənaʊnst ʌðɝ ɝaɪvəlz. dɪmɑndɝɾ ɛntɝd θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ tə ðə saʊθ, ən i wɑz əkʌmpənid baɪ mɛsænə. hæd ðeɪ ɝaɪv təɡɛðɝ, ðɛn?

Her speculation was cut short as footsteps announced other arrivals. Demandred entered through the doorway to the south, and he was accompanied by Mesaana. Had they arrived together, then?

ðeɪ əsum ðət ɡɹeɪndəl dɪd nɑt noʊ ʌv ðɛɹ lɪɾəl əlaɪəns, ə pæk ðəɾ ɪnkluɾəd sɛmɝhɪdʒ. bʌɾ ɑnəsli, ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd tə kip ðəɾ ə sikɹət, kʊdn ðeɪ si ðət ðeɪ ʃʊdn ænsɝ ə sʌmənz təɡɛðɝ?

They assumed that Graendal did not know of their little alliance, a pact that included Semirhage. But honestly, if they wanted to keep that a secret, couldn't they see that they shouldn't answer a summons together?

ɡɹeɪndəl hɪɾ ə smaɪl əz ʃi nɑɾəd tə ðə tu ʌv ðɛm, ðən səlɛktəd ðə lɑɹdʒəst ən moʊs kʌmftəɹbəl-lʊkɪŋ ə ðə ɹumz tʃɛɹz tə sɪɾ ɪn. ʃi ɹæn ə fɪŋɡɝ əlɔŋ ðə smuð, dɑɹk wʊd, filɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪn bɪniθ ðə lækɝ. dɪmɑndɝɾ ən mɛsænə ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ koʊldli, ən ʃi nu ðɛm wɛl ɪnʌf tə pɪk aʊt hɪns ə ðɛɹ sɝpɹaɪz ət siɪŋ hɝ. soʊ. ðeɪ hæɾ æntɪsəpeɪɾəd ðɪs miɾɪŋ, hæd ðeɪ? bʌt nɑt ɡɹeɪndəlz pɹɛzəns əɾ ɪt? bɛs tə pɹitɛn ðət ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz nɑt kənfjuzd. ʃi smaɪl noʊɪŋli ət ðə tu ʌv əm ən kɑɾ ə flæʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ ɪn dɪmɑndɝdz aɪz.

Graendal hid a smile as she nodded to the two of them, then selected the largest and most comfortable-looking of the room's chairs to sit in. She ran a finger along the smooth, dark wood, feeling the grain beneath the lacquer. Demandred and Mesaana regarded her coldly, and she knew them well enough to pick out hints of their surprise at seeing her. So. They had anticipated this meeting, had they? But not Graendal's presence at it? Best to pretend that she herself was not confused. She smiled knowingly at the two of them and caught a flash of anger in Demandred's eyes.

ðət mæn fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi wəd nɛvɝ ədmɪɾ ɪɾ aʊt laʊd. mɛsænə wɑz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi wʌn ʌv wʌt pæs fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðɪs eɪdʒ. ʃi wɑz ɑbviəs ən izi tə ɹid; ɡɹeɪndəlz eɪdʒəns ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ kɛpt əɹ wɛl əpɹaɪzd ə mɛsænəz æktɪvəɾiz. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, ɡɹeɪndəlz oʊn nuli mɪntɪɾ əsoʊsieɪʃən wɪð ɝæŋɡɝ wɑz hɛlpfəl əz wɛl. ɝæŋɡɝ wɑz pleɪɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə wʌnz u wɝ bɪsidʒɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

That man frustrated her, though she would never admit it out loud. Mesaana was in the White Tower, pretending to be one of what passed for an Aes Sedai in this Age. She was obvious and easy to read; Graendal's agents in the White Tower kept her well apprised of Mesaana's activities. And, of course, Graendal's own newly minted association with Aran'gar was helpful as well. Aran'gar was playing with the rebel Aes Sedai, the ones who were besieging the White Tower.

jɛs, mɛsænə dɪd nɑt kənfjuz hɝ, ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ ikwəli izi tə tʃɹæk. mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz fɔɹsɪz fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl, ən ɪz wɔɹ pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz lɛft ɪm vɛɹi lɪɾəl taɪm fəɹ ðə saʊθ - ðoʊ hɪz tu mɪnjənz, sɪndeɪn ən mɑɡiɾin, əkeɪʒənəli ʃoʊd ðɛɹ feɪsəz ðɛɹ. ðeɪ spɛn ðɛɹ taɪm ɹæliɪŋ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən əkeɪʒənəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɑloʊ mɔɹaɪɾɪnz ɔɹɾɝz ðət ðə tu tɑvɝən - pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə ən meɪtʃɹim kɔθən - bi kɪld.

Yes, Mesaana did not confuse her, and the others were equally easy to track. Moridin was gathering the Great Lord's forces for the Last Battle, and his war preparations left him very little time for the south - though his two minions, Cyndane and Moghedien, occasionally showed their faces there. They spent their time rallying the Darkfriends and occasionally trying to follow Moridin's orders that the two ta'veren - Perrin Aybara and Matrim Cauthon - be killed.

ʃi wɑz sɝɾən sɑmaɪl hæd fɔlən tə ɹænd ælθɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə stʃɹʌɡəl fəɹ ɪljən. ɪn fækt - naʊ ðət ɡɹeɪndəl hæɾ ə klu ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd bɪn pʊlɪŋ stʃɹɪŋz wɪð ðə sintʃæn - ʃi wɑz kɑnfəɾənt ʃi nu ðə plænz ʌv ɛvɹi wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ sɛvən ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ tʃoʊzən.

She was certain Sammael had fallen to Rand al'Thor during the struggle for Illian. In fact - now that Graendal had a clue that Semirhage had been pulling strings with the Seanchan - she was confident she knew the plans of every one of the other seven remaining Chosen.

ɪksɛp dɪmɑndɝd.

Except Demandred.

wʌt wɑz ðət blæstəd mæn ʌp tə? ʃiɾ əv tʃɹeɪɾɪd ɔl ə hɝ nɑlədʒ ə mɛsænəz ən ɝæŋɡɝz duɪŋz fəɹ ivən ə hɪn ə dɪmɑndɝdz plænz. hi stʊd ðɛɹ, hænsəm ən hɔk-noʊzd, hɪz lɪps dʒɹɔn ɪn pɝpɛtʃuəl æŋɡɝ. dɪmɑndɝd nɛvɝ smaɪld, nɛvɝ sim tə ɛndʒɔɪ ɛniθɪŋ. ðoʊ hi wɑz wʌn ə ðə fɔɹmoʊs dʒɛnɝəlz əmʌŋ ðə tʃoʊzən, wɔɹfɛɹ hæd nɛvɝ sim tə bɹɪŋ ɪm dʒɔɪ.

What was that blasted man up to? She'd have traded all of her knowledge of Mesaana's and Aran'gar's doings for even a hint of Demandred's plans. He stood there, handsome and hawk-nosed, his lips drawn in perpetual anger. Demandred never smiled, never seemed to enjoy anything. Though he was one of the foremost generals among the Chosen, warfare had never seemed to bring him joy.

wʌns ʃi hæd hɝɾ ɪm seɪ ðəɾ i wəd læf ðə deɪ hi kəd snæp ðə nɛk ə luz θɝɪn. ən oʊnli ðɛn.

Once she had heard him say that he would laugh the day he could snap the neck of Lews Therin. And only then.

hi wɑz ə ful tə bɛɹ ðət ɡɹʌdʒ. tə θɪŋk i maɪɾ əv bɪn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd - maɪɾ əv bɪkʌm ðə dʒɹæɡən hɪmsɛlf, hæd θɪŋz tɝn aʊt dɪfɹənli. stɪl, ful əɹ nɑt, hi wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli deɪnʒɝəs, ən ɡɹeɪndəl dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ ɪɡnɝən ə hɪz plænz. wɛɹ hæɾ i sɛɾ ʌp? dɪmɑndɝd laɪk hævɪŋ ɑɹmiz tə kəmænd, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ nʌn lɛf muvɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld.

He was a fool to bear that grudge. To think he might have been on the other side - might have become the Dragon himself, had things turned out differently. Still, fool or not, he was extremely dangerous, and Graendal did not like being ignorant of his plans. Where had he set up? Demandred liked having armies to command, but there were none left moving in the world.

seɪv pɝhæps fəɹ ðoʊz bɔɹɾɝləndɝz. kəɾ i hæv mænədʒ tə ɪnfɪltʃɹeɪt ðɛm? ðət sɝɾənli wʊɾə bɪn ə ku. bʌt ʃʊɹli ʃiɾ əv hɝd sʌmθɪŋ; ʃi hæd spaɪz ɪn ðət kæmp.

Save perhaps for those Borderlanders. Could he have managed to infiltrate them? That certainly would have been a coup. But surely she'd have heard something; she had spies in that camp.

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ ə dʒɹɪŋk tə wɛɾ əɹ lɪps. ðɪs nɔɹðɝn ɛɹ wɑz tu dʒɹaɪ; ʃi mʌtʃ pɹəfɝd ðə dəmɑni hjumɪɾəti. dɪmɑndɝd foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz, ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ stændɪŋ əz mɛsænə siɾəd hɝsɛlf. ʃi hæd tʃɪn-lɛŋθ dɑɹk hɛɹ ən wɔɾɝi blu aɪz. hɝ flɔɹ-lɛŋθ waɪt dʒɹɛs bɔɹ noʊ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ən ʃi wɔɹ noʊ dʒuəlɹi. ə skɑlɝ tə ðə kɔɹ. səmtaɪmz ɡɹeɪndəl θɔt mɛsænə hæd ɡɔn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ kəz ɪɾ ɔfɝɾ ə mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ ɑpɝtunəɾi fəɹ ɹisɝtʃ.

She shook her head, wishing for a drink to wet her lips. This northern air was too dry; she much preferred the Domani humidity. Demandred folded his arms, remaining standing as Mesaana seated herself. She had chin-length dark hair and watery blue eyes. Her floor-length white dress bore no embroidery, and she wore no jewelry. A scholar to the core. Sometimes Graendal thought Mesaana had gone over to the Shadow because it offered a more interesting opportunity for research.

mɛsænə wɑz fʊli dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd naʊ, dʒʌs laɪk ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm, bʌt ʃi simd ə sɛkənd-ɹeɪt mɛmbɝ ə ðə tʃoʊzən. meɪkɪŋ boʊsts ʃi kʊdn fʊlfɪl, ælaɪɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə stʃɹɔŋɝ pɑɹɾiz bʌt lækɪŋ ðə skɪl tə mənɪpjəleɪt ðɛm. ʃid dʌn ivəl wɝks ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz neɪm, bʌt hæd nɛvɝ mænədʒ ðə ɡɹæn ətʃivməns ə tʃoʊzən laɪk sɛmɝhɪdʒ ən dɪmɑndɝd. lɛɾ əloʊn mɔɹaɪɾɪn.

Mesaana was fully dedicated to the Great Lord now, just like the rest of them, but she seemed a second-rate member of the Chosen. Making boasts she couldn't fulfill, allying herself to stronger parties but lacking the skill to manipulate them. She'd done evil works in the Great Lord's name, but had never managed the grand achievements of Chosen like Semirhage and Demandred. Let alone Moridin.

ænd, əz ɡɹeɪndəl bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ɑn mɔɹaɪɾɪn, ðə mæn ɛntɝd. naʊ, ðəɹ wɑz ə hænsəm kɹitʃɝ. dɪmɑndɝd lʊk laɪk ə nɑb-feɪs pɛzən kəmpɛɹd wɪð hɪm. jɛs, ðɪs bɑɾi wɑz mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən ɪz pɹiviəs wʌn. hi wɑz ɔlmoʊs pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf tə bi wʌn ə hɝ pɛts, ðoʊ ðət tʃɪn spɔɪl ðə feɪs. tu pɹɑmənənt, tu stʃɹɔŋ. stɪl, ðət stɑɹk blæk hɛɹ ətɑp ə tɔl, bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd bɑɾi. . . . ʃi smaɪld, θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɪm nilɪŋ ɪn ə fɪlmi aʊtfɪɾ ʌv waɪt, lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ ədɔɝɪŋli, hɪz maɪn ɹæpt ɪn kəmpʌlʃən tə ðə pɔɪn ðəɾ i sɔ noʊbɑdi - nʌθɪŋ - ʌðɝ ðən ɡɹeɪndəl.

And, as Graendal began to think on Moridin, the man entered. Now, there was a handsome creature. Demandred looked like a knob-faced peasant compared with him. Yes, this body was much better than his previous one. He was almost pretty enough to be one of her pets, though that chin spoiled the face. Too prominent, too strong. Still, that stark black hair atop a tall, broad-shouldered body. . . . She smiled, thinking of him kneeling in a filmy outfit of white, looking at her adoringly, his mind wrapped in Compulsion to the point that he saw nobody - nothing - other than Graendal.

mɛsænə ɹoʊz əz sun əz mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɛntɝd, ən ɡɹeɪndəl ɹɪlʌktənli dɪd laɪkwaɪz. hi wɑzn əɹ pɛt, nɑt jɛt. hi wɑz nɛbli, ən i hæd bɪɡʌn tə dɪmæn mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ʃoʊz ʌv oʊbiɾiəns fɹəm əm ɪn ɹisən deɪz. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd ɡeɪv ɪm ði əθɔɹəɾi. ɔl θɹi ʌv ði ʌðɝ tʃoʊzən ɹɪlʌktənli baʊd ðɛɹ hɛdz tə hɪm; oʊnli tə hɪm əmʌŋ ɔl mɛn wəd ðeɪ ʃoʊ dɛfɝəns. hi noʊɾəd ðɛɹ oʊbiɾiəns wɪð stɝn aɪz əz i stɔk tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə ɹum, wɛɹ ðə wɔl ə tʃɑɹkoʊl blæk stoʊnz wɑz sɛt wɪð ə mæntəl. wʌt hæd pəzɛst sʌmwʌn tə bɪld ə fɔɹtʃɹəs aʊɾ ə blæk ɹɑk ɪn ðə blaɪts hit?

Mesaana rose as soon as Moridin entered, and Graendal reluctantly did likewise. He wasn't her pet, not yet. He was Nae'blis, and he had begun to demand more and more shows of obedience from them in recent days. The Great Lord gave him the authority. All three of the other Chosen reluctantly bowed their heads to him; only to him among all men would they show deference. He noted their obedience with stern eyes as he stalked to the front of the room, where the wall of charcoal black stones was set with a mantel. What had possessed someone to build a fortress out of black rock in the Blight's heat?

ɡɹeɪndəl sæt bæk daʊn. wɝ ði ʌðɝ tʃoʊzən kʌmɪŋ? ɪf nɑt, wʌɾ ɪt min?

Graendal sat back down. Were the other Chosen coming? If not, what did it mean?

mɛsænə spoʊk bɪfɔɹ mɔɹaɪɾɪn kəd seɪ ɛniθɪŋ. "mɔɹaɪɾɪn," ʃi sɛd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, "wi nid tə ɹɛskju hɝ."

Mesaana spoke before Moridin could say anything. "Moridin," she said, stepping forward, "we need to rescue her."

"ju wɪl spik wən aɪ ɡɪv jə liv, mɛsænə," hi ɹɪplaɪd koʊldli. "ju ɑɹ nɑt jɛt fɝɡɪvən."

"You will speak when I give you leave, Mesaana," he replied coldly. "You are not yet forgiven."

ʃi kɹɪnʒd, ðən ɑbviəsli ɡɹu æŋɡɹi ət hɝsɛlf fəɹ ɪt. mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ət ɡɹeɪndəl, aɪz nɛɹoʊ. wʌt wɑz ðət lʊk fɔɹ?

She cringed, then obviously grew angry at herself for it. Moridin ignored her, glancing over at Graendal, eyes narrow. What was that look for?

"ju meɪ kəntɪnju," hi faɪnəli sɛd tə mɛsænə, "bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ jəɹ pleɪs."

"You may continue," he finally said to Mesaana, "but remember your place."

mɛsænəz lɪps fɔɹmd ə laɪn, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɑɹɡju. "mɔɹaɪɾɪn," ʃi sɛd, toʊn lɛs dɪmændɪŋ.

Mesaana's lips formed a line, but she did not argue. "Moridin," she said, tone less demanding.

"ju sɔ ðə wɪzdəm ɪn əɡɹiɪŋ tə mit wɪð ʌs. ʃʊɹli ðət wɑz kəz jə ɑɹ əz ʃɑkt əz wi ɑɹ. wi də nɑɾ əv ðə ɹisɔɹsɪz tə hɛlp əɹ aʊɝsɛlvz; ʃiz baʊn tə bi wɛl ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðoʊz æʃəmən. jə nid tə hɛlp əs fɹi hɝ."

"You saw the wisdom in agreeing to meet with us. Surely that was because you are as shocked as we are. We do not have the resources to help her ourselves; she is bound to be well guarded by Aes Sedai and those Asha'man. You need to help us free her."

"sɛmɝhɪdʒ dɪzɝvz əɹ ɪmpɹɪzənmənt," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, ɹɛstɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm ɑn ðə mæntəl, stɪl tɝn əweɪ fɹəm mɛsænə.

"Semirhage deserves her imprisonment," Moridin said, resting his arm on the mantel, still turned away from Mesaana.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ, kæptʃɝd? ɡɹeɪndəl hæd dʒʌs bɛɹli lɝn ðət ðə wʊmən wɑz ɪmpɝsəneɪɾɪŋ ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt sintʃæn! wʌt hæd ʃi dʌn tə ɡɛt hɝsɛlf kæptʃɝd? ɪf ðəɹ wɝ æʃəmən, ðən ɪt simd ʃid mænədʒ tə bi teɪkən baɪ ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf!

Semirhage, captured? Graendal had just barely learned that the woman was impersonating an important Seanchan! What had she done to get herself captured? If there were Asha'man, then it seemed she'd managed to be taken by al'Thor himself!

dɪspaɪɾ əɹ stɑɹɾəlmənt, ɡɹeɪndəl meɪnteɪn əɹ noʊɪŋ smaɪl. dɪmɑndɝd ɡlænst ət hɝ. ɪf i ən mɛsænə hæɾ æsk fəɹ ðɪs miɾɪŋ, ðən waɪ hæd mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛn fəɹ ɡɹeɪndəl?

Despite her startlement, Graendal maintained her knowing smile. Demandred glanced at her. If he and Mesaana had asked for this meeting, then why had Moridin sent for Graendal?

"bʌt θɪŋk ʌv wʌt sɛmɝhɪdʒ maɪt ɹɪvil!" mɛsænə sɛd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɡɹeɪndəl. "bɪɑn ðæt, ʃiz wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən. ɪts əɹ duɾi tə eɪd hɝ."

"But think of what Semirhage might reveal!" Mesaana said, ignoring Graendal. "Beyond that, she is one of the Chosen. It is our duty to aid her."

ən bɪɑn ðæt, ɡɹeɪndəl θɔt, ʃiz ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə lɪɾəl əlaɪəns jə tu meɪd.

And beyond that, Graendal thought, she is a member of the little alliance you two made.

pɝhæps ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs mɛmbɝ. luzɪŋ əɹ wɪl bi ə bloʊ tə jəɹ bɪd fəɹ kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə tʃoʊzən.

Perhaps the strongest member. Losing her will be a blow to your bid for control of the Chosen.

"ʃi dɪsoʊbeɪd," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd. "ʃi wɑz nɑt tə tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl ælθɹ."

"She disobeyed," Moridin said. "She was not to try to kill al'Thor."

"ʃi dɪdn ɪntɛn tə," mɛsænə sɛd heɪstəli. "aʊɝ wʊmən ðəɹ θɪŋks ðət ðə boʊlt ə faɪɝ wɑz ə ɹiækʃən ə sɝpɹaɪz, nɑɾ ən ɪntɛntʃən tə kɪl."

"She didn't intend to," Mesaana said hastily. "Our woman there thinks that the bolt of Fire was a reaction of surprise, not an intention to kill."

"ænd wʌt seɪ jə ʌv ðɪs, dɪmɑndɝd?" mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ mæn.

"And what say you of this, Demandred?" Moridin said, glancing at the shorter man.

"aɪ wɑn luz θɝɪn," dɪmɑndɝd sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs dip, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən dɑɹk, əz ɔlweɪz.

"I want Lews Therin," Demandred said, his voice deep, his expression dark, as always.

"sɛmɝhɪdʒ noʊz ðæt. ʃi ɔlsoʊ noʊz ðəɾ ɪf ʃid kɪl hɪm, aɪ wʊɾə faʊn əɹ ən kleɪmd əɹ laɪf ɪn ɹɛtʃɹəbjuʃən. noʊbɑdi kɪlz ælθɹ. noʊbɑdi bʌt mi."

"Semirhage knows that. She also knows that if she'd killed him, I would have found her and claimed her life in retribution. Nobody kills al'Thor. Nobody but me."

"ju əɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, dɪmɑndɝd," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, vɔɪs deɪnʒɝəs. "hɪz wɪl dɑməneɪts əs ɔl."

"You or the Great Lord, Demandred," Moridin said, voice dangerous. "His will dominates us all."

"jɛs, jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs ɪt dʌz," mɛsænə kʌɾ ɪn, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, pleɪn dʒɹɛs bɹʌʃɪŋ ðə mɪɹɝ- bɹaɪt blæk mɑɹbəl flɔɹ. "mɔɹaɪɾɪn, ðə fækt ɹɪmeɪnz ðət ʃi dɪdn ɪntɛn tə kɪl hɪm, dʒʌs tə kæptʃɝ hɪm. aɪ - "

"Yes, yes, of course it does," Mesaana cut in, stepping forward, plain dress brushing the mirror- bright black marble floor. "Moridin, the fact remains that she didn't intend to kill him, just to capture him. I - "

"ʌv kɔɹs ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə kæptʃɝ hɪm!" mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɹɔɹd, kɑzɪŋ mɛsænə tə flɪntʃ. "ðæt wɑz wʌt ʃi wɑz ɔɹɾɝd tə du. ən ʃi feɪld əɾ ɪt, mɛsænə. feɪl spɛktækjəlɝli, livɪŋ ɪm wundəd dɪspaɪt maɪ ɪkspɹɛs kəmæn ðəɾ i wɑzn tə bi hɑɹmd! ən fəɹ ðəɾ ɪnkɑmpəɾəns, ʃɪl sʌfɝ. əl ɡɪv jə noʊ eɪɾ ɪn ɹɛskjuɪŋ hɝ. ɪn fækt, aɪ fɝbɪd jə tə sɛn əɹ eɪd. dʒju ʌndɝstænd?"

"Of course she intended to capture him!" Moridin roared, causing Mesaana to flinch. "That was what she was ordered to do. And she failed at it, Mesaana. Failed spectacularly, leaving him wounded despite my express command that he wasn't to be harmed! And for that incompetence, she will suffer. I will give you no aid in rescuing her. In fact, I forbid you to send her aid. Do you understand?"

mɛsænə flɪntʃt əɡɛn. dɪmɑndɝd dɪd nɑt; hi mɛt mɔɹaɪɾɪnz aɪz, ðən nɑɾəd. jɛs, hi wɑz ə koʊld wʌn. pɝhæps ɡɹeɪndəl ʌndɝɛstəmeɪɾɪd hɪm. hi vɛɹi wɛl maɪt bi ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə ðə θɹi, mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən sɛmɝhɪdʒ. ʃi wɑz ɪmoʊʃənləs ən kəntʃɹoʊld, tʃɹu, bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪmoʊʃən wɑz əpɹoʊpɹiət. ɪt kəd dʒɹaɪv ə mæn laɪk dɪmɑndɝd tə ækʃənz ðəɾ ə mɔɹ kulhɛɾɪd pɝsən kʊdn ivən kɑntəmpleɪt.

Mesaana flinched again. Demandred did not; he met Moridin's eyes, then nodded. Yes, he was a cold one. Perhaps Graendal underestimated him. He very well might be the most powerful of the three, more dangerous than Semirhage. She was emotionless and controlled, true, but sometimes emotion was appropriate. It could drive a man like Demandred to actions that a more coolheaded person couldn't even contemplate.

mɔɹaɪɾɪn lʊk daʊn, flɛksɪŋ ɪz lɛf hænd, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ stɪf. ɡɹeɪndəl kɑɾ ə hɪn ə peɪn ɪn ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Moridin looked down, flexing his left hand, as if it were stiff. Graendal caught a hint of pain in his expression.

"lɛt sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɹɑt," mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɡɹaʊld. "lɛɾ əɹ si wʌɾ ɪts tə bi ðə wʌn kwɛstʃənd. pɝhæps ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wɪl faɪn səm jus fəɹ əɹ ɪn ðə kʌmɪŋ wiks, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz ɪz tə dətɝmən. naʊ. tɛl mi ʌv jəɹ pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz."

"Let Semirhage rot," Moridin growled. "Let her see what it is to be the one questioned. Perhaps the Great Lord will find some use for her in the coming weeks, but that is his to determine. Now. Tell me of your preparations."

mɛsænə peɪl dʒʌst slaɪtli, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ɡɹeɪndəl. dɪmɑndɝdz feɪs ɡɹu ɹɛd, əz ɪf i wɑz ɪnkɹɛdʒələs ðət ðeɪ wəd bi ɪntɛɹəɡeɪɾɪd ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ənʌðɝ tʃoʊzən. ɡɹeɪndəl smaɪld ət ðɛm.

Mesaana paled just slightly, glancing at Graendal. Demandred's face grew red, as if he was incredulous that they would be interrogated in front of another Chosen. Graendal smiled at them.

"aɪ æm pɝfəkli pɔɪzd," mɛsænə sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɪð ə swip ə hɝ hɛd. "ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən ðoʊz fulz u ɹul ɪɾəl ʃɔɹtli bi maɪn. əl dɪlɪvɝ nɑt dʒʌst ə bɹoʊkən waɪt taʊɝ tə əɹ ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, bʌɾ ən ɪntaɪɝ bɹuɾ ə tʃænlɝz u - wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ - wɪl sɝv əɹ kɑz ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl. ðɪs taɪm, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl faɪt fəɹ ʌs!"

"I am perfectly poised," Mesaana said, turning back to Moridin with a sweep of her head. "The White Tower and those fools who rule it will shortly be mine. I will deliver not just a broken White Tower to our Great Lord, but an entire brood of channelers who - one way or another - will serve our cause in the Last Battle. This time, the Aes Sedai will fight for us!"

"ə boʊl kleɪm," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd.

"A bold claim," Moridin said.

"aɪ wɪl meɪk ɪt hæpən," mɛsænə sɛɾ ivənli. "maɪ fɑloʊɝz ənfɛs ðə taʊɝ laɪk ən ənsin pleɪɡ, fɛstɝɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ʌv ə hɛlθi-lʊkɪŋ mæn ət mɑɹkət. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ dʒɔɪn əɹ kɑz. səm ɪntɛnʃənəli, ʌðɝz ənwɪɾɪŋli. ɪts ðə seɪm iðɝ weɪ."

"I will make it happen," Mesaana said evenly. "My followers infest the Tower like an unseen plague, festering inside of a healthy-looking man at market. More and more join our cause. Some intentionally, others unwittingly. It is the same either way."

ɡɹeɪndəl lɪsən θɔtfəli. ɝæŋɡɝ kleɪm ðət ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli sɪkjʊɹ ðə taʊɝ, ðoʊ ɡɹeɪndəl hɝsɛlf wɑzn sɝɾən. hu wəd bi vɪktɔɹiəs, ðə tʃaɪld əɹ ðə ful? dɪɾ ɪt mæɾɝ?

Graendal listened thoughtfully. Aran'gar claimed that the rebel Aes Sedai would eventually secure the Tower, though Graendal herself wasn't certain. Who would be victorious, the child or the fool? Did it matter?

"æn ju?" mɔɹaɪɾɪn æsk dɪmɑndɝd.

"And you?" Moridin asked Demandred.

"maɪ ɹul ɪz sɪkjʊɹ," dɪmɑndɝd sɛd sɪmpli. "aɪ ɡæðɝ fəɹ wɔɹ. wɪl bi ɹɛɾi."

"My rule is secure," Demandred said simply. "I gather for war. We will be ready."

ɡɹeɪndəl ɪtʃt fəɹ ɪm tə seɪ mɔɹ ðən ðæt, bʌt mɔɹaɪɾɪn dɪd nɑt pʊʃ. stɪl, ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ʃid bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡlin ɑn əɹ oʊn. dɪmɑndɝɾ əpɛɹənli hɛld ə θɹoʊn ən hæɾ ɑɹmiz. wɪtʃ wɝ ɡæðɝd. ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz mɑɹtʃɪŋ θɹu ði ist simd mɔɹ ən mɔɹ laɪkli.

Graendal itched for him to say more than that, but Moridin did not push. Still, it was much more than she'd been able to glean on her own. Demandred apparently held a throne and had armies. Which were gathered. The Borderlanders marching through the east seemed more and more likely.

"ju tu meɪ wɪðdʒɹɔ," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd.

"You two may withdraw," Moridin said.

mɛsænə spʌɾɝd ət ðə dɪsmɪsəl, bʌt dɪmɑndɝd sɪmpli tɝn ən stɔkt əweɪ. ɡɹeɪndəl nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf; ʃiɾ əv tə wɑtʃ hɪm. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd feɪvɝɾ ækʃən, ən ɔfən ðoʊz u kəd bɹɪŋ ɑɹmiz tə hɪz neɪm wɝ bɛst ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd. dɪmɑndɝd kəd vɛɹi wɛl bi hɝ moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɹaɪvəl - fɑloʊɪŋ mɔɹaɪɾɪn hɪmsɛlf, ʌv kɔɹs.

Mesaana sputtered at the dismissal, but Demandred simply turned and stalked away. Graendal nodded to herself; she'd have to watch him. The Great Lord favored action, and often those who could bring armies to his name were best rewarded. Demandred could very well be her most important rival - following Moridin himself, of course.

hi hæd nɑt dɪsmɪs hɝ, ən soʊ ʃi ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd əz ði ʌðɝ tu wɪθdʒɹu. mɔɹaɪɾɪn steɪd wɛɹ i wɑz, wʌn ɑɹm linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə mæntəl. ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns ɪn ðə tu-blæk ɹum fəɹ ə taɪm, ən ðən ə sɝvən ɪn ə kɹɪsp ɹɛd junəfɔɹm ɛntɝd, bɛɹɪŋ tu kʌps. hi wɑz ən ʌɡli θɪŋ, wɪð ə flæt feɪs ən bʊʃi aɪbɹaʊz, wɝθ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə pæsɪŋ ɡlæns.

He had not dismissed her, and so she remained seated as the other two withdrew. Moridin stayed where he was, one arm leaning against the mantel. There was silence in the too-black room for a time, and then a servant in a crisp red uniform entered, bearing two cups. He was an ugly thing, with a flat face and bushy eyebrows, worth no more than a passing glance.

ʃi tʊk ə sɪp ə hɝ dʒɹɪŋk ən teɪstəd nu waɪn, dʒʌst slaɪtli tɑɹt, bʌt kwaɪt ɡʊd. ɪt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɑɹd tə faɪnd ɡʊd waɪn; ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz tʌtʃ ɑn ðə wɝl teɪntɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, spɔɪlɪŋ fud, ɹuɪnɪŋ ivən ðət wɪtʃ nɛvɝ ʃʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə spɔɪl.

She took a sip of her drink and tasted new wine, just slightly tart, but quite good. It was growing hard to find good wine; the Great Lord's touch on the world tainted everything, spoiling food, ruining even that which never should have been able to spoil.

mɔɹaɪɾɪn weɪv ðə sɝvən əweɪ, nɑt teɪkɪŋ ɪz oʊn kʌp. ɡɹeɪndəl fɪɹd pɔɪzən, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi ɔlweɪz dɪd wən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ fɹəm ənʌðɝz kʌp. haʊɛvɝ, ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ ɹizən fəɹ mɔɹaɪɾɪn tə pɔɪzən hɝ; hi wɑz nɛbli. waɪl moʊst ə ðɛm ɹɪzɪstɪd ʃoʊɪŋ səbsɝviəns tə hɪm, mɔɹ ən mɔɹ i wɑz ɪɡzɝɾɪŋ ɪz wɪl ɑn ðɛm, pʊʃɪŋ əm ɪndə pəzɪʃənz əz ɪz lɛsɝz. ʃi səspɛktəd ðæt, ɪf i wɪʃt, hi kəɾ əv əɹ ɛksəkjuɾəd ɪn ɛni mænɝ ʌv weɪz ən ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wəd ɡɹæn ɪt tə hɪm. soʊ ʃi dʒɹæŋk ən weɪɾəd.

Moridin waved the servant away, not taking his own cup. Graendal feared poison, of course. She always did when drinking from another's cup. However, there would be no reason for Moridin to poison her; he was Nae'blis. While most of them resisted showing subservience to him, more and more he was exerting his will on them, pushing them into positions as his lessers. She suspected that, if he wished, he could have her executed in any manner of ways and the Great Lord would grant it to him. So she drank and waited.

"dɪd jə ɡlin mʌtʃ fɹəm wʌt jə hɝd, ɡɹeɪndəl?" mɔɹaɪɾɪn æskt.

"Did you glean much from what you heard, Graendal?" Moridin asked.

"æz mʌtʃ əz kəd bi ɡlind," ʃi ænsɝd kɛɹfəli.

"As much as could be gleaned," she answered carefully.

"aɪ noʊ haʊ jə kɹeɪv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. mɑɡiɾin əz ɔlweɪz bɪn noʊn əz ðə spaɪɾɝ, pʊlɪŋ stʃɹɪŋz fɹəm əfɑɹ, bʌt jə ɑɹ ɪn mɛni weɪz bɛɾɝ əɾ ɪt ðən ʃi. ʃi wɪnz soʊ mɛni wɛbz ðət ʃi ɡɛts kɑɾ ɪn ðɛm. jə ɑɹ mɔɹ kɛɹfəl. jə stʃɹaɪk oʊnli wən waɪz, bʌɾ ɑɹ nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə kənflɪkt. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ əpɹuvz ə jəɹ ɪnɪʃəɾɪv."

"I know how you crave information. Moghedien has always been known as the spider, pulling strings from afar, but you are in many ways better at it than she. She winds so many webs that she gets caught in them. You are more careful. You strike only when wise, but are not afraid of conflict. The Great Lord approves of your initiative."

"maɪ dɪɹ mɔɹaɪɾɪn," ʃi sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, "ju flæɾɝ mi."

"My dear Moridin," she said, smiling to herself, "you flatter me."

"du nɑt tɔɪ wɪð mi, ɡɹeɪndəl," hi sɛd, vɔɪs hɑɹd. "teɪk jəɹ kɑmpləməns ən bi saɪlənt."

"Do not toy with me, Graendal," he said, voice hard. "Take your compliments and be silent."

ʃi ɹikɔɪld əz ɪf slæpt, bʌt sɛd noʊ mɔɹ.

She recoiled as if slapped, but said no more.

"aɪ ɡeɪv jə liv tə lɪsən tə ði ʌðɝ tu əz ə ɹɪwɔɹd," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd. "nɛbli hæz bɪn tʃoʊzən, bʌt ðəɹ wɪl bi ʌðɝ pəzɪʃənz ə haɪ ɡlɔɹi ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz ɹeɪn. səm mʌtʃ haɪɝ ðən ʌðɝz. tədeɪ wɑz ə teɪst ə ðə pɹɪvlədʒəz jə maɪɾ ɛndʒɔɪ."

"I gave you leave to listen to the other two as a reward," Moridin said. "Nae'blis has been chosen, but there will be other positions of high glory in the Great Lord's reign. Some much higher than others. Today was a taste of the privileges you might enjoy."

"aɪ laɪv oʊnli tə sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd."

"I live only to serve the Great Lord."

"ðɛn sɝv ɪm ɪn ðɪs," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ dɝɛkli ət hɝ. "ælθɹ muvz fəɹ ɑɹæd dumən.

"Then serve him in this," Moridin said, looking directly at her. "Al'Thor moves for Arad Doman.

hiz tə lɪv ənhɑɹmd əntɪl i kən feɪs mi ət ðət læs deɪ. bʌɾ i mʌs nɑt bi əlaʊd tə meɪk pis ɪn jəɹ lænz. hɪl ətɛmp tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ. jə mʌs faɪnd weɪz tə pɹɪvɛn ðət fɹəm hæpənɪŋ."

He is to live unharmed until he can face me at that last day. But he must not be allowed to make peace in your lands. He will attempt to restore order. You must find ways to prevent that from happening."

"ɪt wɪl bi dʌn."

"It will be done."

"ɡoʊ, ðɛn," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ə hænd ʃɑɹpli.

"Go, then," Moridin said, waving a hand sharply.

ʃi ɹoʊz, θɔtfəl, ən stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ.

She rose, thoughtful, and started toward the door.

"ænd ɡɹeɪndəl," hi sɛd.

"And Graendal," he said.

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət hɪm. hi stʊɾ əɡɛns ðə mæntəl, bæk moʊsli tə hɝ. hi sim tə bi stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ, dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ ət ðə blæk stoʊnz ə ðə fɑɹ wɔl. stʃɹeɪnʒli, hi lʊkt ə ɡɹeɪt dil laɪk ælθɹ - ʌv hum ʃi hæd numɝəs skɛtʃəz vaɪə hɝ spaɪz - wən i stʊd laɪk ðæt.

She hesitated, glancing at him. He stood against the mantel, back mostly to her. He seemed to be staring at nothing, just looking at the black stones of the far wall. Strangely, he looked a great deal like al'Thor - of whom she had numerous sketches via her spies - when he stood like that.

"ði ɛn ɪz nɪɹ," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd. "ðə wil əz ɡɹoʊn ɪts faɪnəl ɹoʊteɪʃən, ðə klɑk əz lɔst ɪts spɹɪŋ, ðə sɝpən hivz ɪts faɪnəl ɡæsps. hi mʌs noʊ peɪn ə hɑɹt. hi mʌs noʊ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, ən i mʌs noʊ æŋɡwɪʃ. bɹɪŋ ðiz tə hɪm. ən jəl bi ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd."

"The end is near," Moridin said. "The Wheel has groaned its final rotation, the clock has lost its spring, the serpent heaves its final gasps. He must know pain of heart. He must know frustration, and he must know anguish. Bring these to him. And you will be rewarded."

ʃi nɑɾəd, ðən meɪɾ əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə pɹəvaɪɾəd ɡeɪtweɪ, bæk tə hɝ stʃɹɔŋhoʊld ɪn ðə hɪlz ʌv ɑɹæd dumən.

She nodded, then made her way through the provided gateway, back to her stronghold in the hills of Arad Doman.

tə plɑt.

To plot.

ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldiz mʌðɝ, naʊ θɝɾi jɪɹz bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə kleɪ hɪlz ə hɪz dəmɑni hoʊmlænd, hæd bɪn fɑn ʌv ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ seɪɪŋ: "θɪŋz ɔlweɪz əv tə ɡɛt wɝs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən ɡɛt bɛɾɝ." ʃid sɛɾ ɪt wən ʃid jæŋk fɹi hɪz fɛstɝɪŋ tuθ əz ə bɔɪ, ən eɪlmən hiɾ ɝnd waɪl pleɪɪŋ ət sɔɹdz wɪð ðə vɪlədʒ bɔɪz. ʃid sɛɾ ɪt wən hid lɔst ɪz fɝs lʌv tə ə lɔɹɾəlɪŋ u wɔɹ ə hæt wɪð fɛðɝz ən huz sɑf hænz ən dʒuəl sɔɹd hæd pɹuvən hid nɛvɝ noʊn ə ɹil bæɾəl.

Rodel Ituralde's mother, now thirty years buried in the clay hills of his Domani homeland, had been fond of a particular saying: "Things always have to get worse before they can get better." She'd said it when she'd yanked free his festering tooth as a boy, an ailment he'd earned while playing at swords with the village boys. She'd said it when he'd lost his first love to a lordling who wore a hat with feathers and whose soft hands and jeweled sword had proven he'd never known a real battle.

ən ʃid seɪ ɪt naʊ, ɪf ʃi wɝ wɪð ɪm ɑn ðə ɹɪdʒ, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə sintʃæn mɑɹtʃ əpɑn ðə sɪɾi nɛsəld ɪn ðə ʃæloʊ væli bɪloʊ.

And she'd say it now, if she were with him on the ridge, watching the Seanchan march upon the city nestled in the shallow valley below.

hi stʌɾid ðə sɪɾi, dɑɹlunə, θɹu hɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, ʃeɪɾɪŋ ði ɛnd wɪð ɪz lɛf hænd, hɪz ɡɛldɪŋ kwaɪət bɪniθ ɪm ɪn ði ivnɪŋ laɪt. hi ən sɛvɹəl ə hɪz dəmɑni kɛp tə ðɪs smɔl stæn ə tʃɹiz; ɪt wəd teɪk ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn lʌk fəɹ ðə sintʃæn tə spɑt hɪm, ivən wɪð lʊkɪŋ ɡlæsəz ə ðɛɹ oʊn.

He studied the city, Darluna, through his looking glass, shading the end with his left hand, his gelding quiet beneath him in the evening light. He and several of his Domani kept to this small stand of trees; it would take the Dark One's own luck for the Seanchan to spot him, even with looking glasses of their own.

θɪŋz ɔlweɪz hæd tə ɡɛt wɝs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd ɡɛt bɛɾɝ. hid lɪɾ ə faɪɝ ʌndɝ ðə sintʃæn baɪ dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ðɛɹ səplaɪ dipoʊz ɔl əkɹɔs ɑlməθ pleɪn ən ɪndə tæɹɑbən. hi ʃʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪzd, ðɛn, tə si ə ɡɹæn ɑɹmi laɪk ðɪs wʌn - ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti θaʊzən stʃɹɔŋ ət list - kʌm tə kwɛntʃ ðət faɪɝ. ɪt ʃoʊɾ ə mɛʒɝ ə ɹɪspɛkt. ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝɛstəmeɪt hɪm, ðiz sintʃæn ɪnveɪɾɝz.

Things always had to get worse before they could get better. He'd lit a fire under the Seanchan by destroying their supply depots all across Almoth Plain and into Tarabon. He shouldn't be surprised, then, to see a grand army like this one - a hundred and fifty thousand strong at least - come to quench that fire. It showed a measure of respect. They did not underestimate him, these Seanchan invaders.

hi wɪʃt ðət ðeɪ dɪd.

He wished that they did.

ɪɾɝɑldi muvd ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, stʌɾiɪŋ ə ɡɹup ə ɹaɪɾɝz əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn fɔɹs. ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn pɛɹz, wʌn wʊmən ʌv itʃ pɛɹ wɛɹɪŋ ɡɹeɪ, ði ʌðɝ ɹɛɾ ən blu. ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ tu dɪstənt, ivən wɪð ðə ɡlæs, fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk aʊt ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd laɪtnɪŋ boʊls ɑn ðə dʒɹɛsəz ə ðoʊz ɪn ɹɛɾ ən blu, nɔɹ kəɾ i si ðə tʃeɪnz ðət lɪŋkt itʃ pɛɹ təɡɛðɝ. deɪmeɪn ən sʌldəm.

Ituralde moved his looking glass, studying a group of riders among the Seanchan force. They rode in pairs, one woman of each pair wearing gray, the other red and blue. They were far too distant, even with the glass, for him to make out the embroidered lightning bolts on the dresses of those in red and blue, nor could he see the chains that linked each pair together. Damane and sul'dam.

ðɪs ɑɹmi hæɾ ət list ə hʌnʒɹəd pɛɹz, pɹɑbli mɔɹ. ɪf ðət wɝn ɪnʌf, hi kəd si wʌn ə ðə flaɪɪŋ bists əbʌv, dʒɹɔɪŋ kloʊs fəɹ ɪts ɹaɪɾɝ tə dʒɹɑp ə mɛsədʒ tə ðə dʒɛnɝəl. wɪð ðoʊz kɹitʃɝz tə kæɹi ðɛɹ skaʊts, ðə sintʃæn ɑɹmi hæɾ ən ənpɹɛsɪdɛntɪɾ ɛdʒ. ɪɾɝɑldi wʊɾə tʃɹeɪɾɪd tɛn θaʊzən soʊlʒɝz fəɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz flaɪɪŋ bists. ʌðɝ kəmændɝz maɪɾ əv wɑntəd ðə deɪmeɪn, wɪð ðɛɹ əbɪləɾi tə θɹoʊ laɪtnɪŋz ən kɑz ði ɝθ tə hiv, bʌt bæɾəlz - laɪk wɔɹz -  wɝ wʌn baɪ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əz ɔfən əz ðeɪ wɝ baɪ wɛpənz.

This army had at least a hundred pairs, probably more. If that weren't enough, he could see one of the flying beasts above, drawing close for its rider to drop a message to the general. With those creatures to carry their scouts, the Seanchan army had an unprecedented edge. Ituralde would have traded ten thousand soldiers for one of those flying beasts. Other commanders might have wanted the damane, with their ability to throw lightnings and cause the earth to heave, but battles - like wars -  were won by information as often as they were by weapons.

ʌv kɔɹs, ðə sintʃæn hæd supɪɹiɝ wɛpənz əz wɛl əz supɪɹiɝ skaʊts. ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ hæd supɪɹiɝ tʃɹups. ðoʊ ɪɾɝɑldi wɑz pɹaʊɾ ə hɪz dəmɑni, mɛni ʌv ɪz mɛn wɝ ɪl tʃɹeɪn əɹ tu oʊl fəɹ faɪɾɪŋ. hi ɔlmoʊs lʌmp hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðət læɾɝ ɡɹup, əz ðə jɪɹz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə paɪl ɑn ɪm laɪk bɹɪks ɑn ə pælət. bʌɾ i ɡeɪv noʊ θɔt tə ɹɪtaɪɹɪŋ. wən hid bɪn ə bɔɪ, hiɾ ɔfən fɛlt ə sɛns ə ɝdʒənsi - ə wɝi ðət baɪ ðə taɪm i keɪm ʌv eɪdʒ, ðə ɡɹeɪt bæɾəlz wəɾ ɔl bi dʌn, ɔl ðə ɡlɔɹi wʌn.

Of course, the Seanchan had superior weapons as well as superior scouts. They also had superior troops. Though Ituralde was proud of his Domani, many of his men were ill trained or too old for fighting. He almost lumped himself in that latter group, as the years were beginning to pile on him like bricks on a pallet. But he gave no thought to retiring. When he'd been a boy, he'd often felt a sense of urgency - a worry that by the time he came of age, the great battles would all be done, all the glory won.

səmtaɪmz, hi ɛnvid bɔɪz ðɛɹ fulɪʃnəs.

Sometimes, he envied boys their foolishness.

"ðeɪ mɑɹtʃ hɑɹd, ɹoʊɾəl," lɪdʒɹɪn sɛd. hi wɑz ə juθ wɪð ə skɑɹ əkɹɔs ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə hɪz feɪs, ən i wɔɹ ə fæʃənəbəl θɪn blæk mʌstæʃ. "ðeɪ bædli wɑnə kæptʃɝ ðət sɪɾi." lɪdʒɹɪn hæd bɪn əntɛstɪɾ əz ən ɔfəsɝ bɪfɔɹ ðɪs kæmpeɪn bɪɡæn. hi wɑz ə vɛɾɝən naʊ. ɔlðoʊ ɪɾɝɑldi ən ɪz fɔɹsɪz hæd wʌn nɪɹli ɛvɹi ɛnɡeɪdʒmən ðeɪd hæd wɪð ðə sintʃæn, lɪdʒɹɪn hæd sin θɹi ʌv ɪz kəmpænjən ɔfəsɝz fɔl, pʊɹ dʒæləm niʃɝ əmʌŋ ðɛm. fɹəm ðɛɹ dɛθs, lɪdʒɹɪn hæd lɝnd wʌn ə ðə bɪɾɝ lɛsənz ʌv wɔɹfɛɹ: wɪnɪŋ dɪdnt nɛsəsɛɹəli min lɪvɪŋ. ən fɑloʊɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz ɔfən dɪdn min iðɝ wɪnɪŋ əɹ lɪvɪŋ.

"They march hard, Rodel," Lidrin said. He was a youth with a scar across the left side of his face, and he wore a fashionable thin black mustache. "They badly want to capture that city." Lidrin had been untested as an officer before this campaign began. He was a veteran now. Although Ituralde and his forces had won nearly every engagement they'd had with the Seanchan, Lidrin had seen three of his companion officers fall, poor Jaalam Nishur among them. From their deaths, Lidrin had learned one of the bitter lessons of warfare: winning didn't necessarily mean living. And following orders often didn't mean either winning or living.

lɪdʒɹɪn dɪdnt wɛɹ ɪz kʌstəmɛɹi junəfɔɹm. niðɝ dɪɾ ɪɾɝɑldi əɹ ɛni ʌv ðə mɛn wɪð hɪm. ðɛɹ junəfɔɹmz hæd bɪn niɾəd ɛlswɛɹ, ən ðət lɛft əm wɪð sɪmpəl wɔɹn koʊts ən bɹaʊn tʃɹaʊzɝz, mɛni bɑɹoʊɾ əɹ bɑt fɹəm loʊkəlz.

Lidrin didn't wear his customary uniform. Neither did Ituralde or any of the men with him. Their uniforms had been needed elsewhere, and that left them with simple worn coats and brown trousers, many borrowed or bought from locals.

ɪɾɝɑldi ɹeɪzd ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs əɡɛn, θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn lɪdʒɹɪnz kɑmɛnt. ðə sintʃæn dɪɾ ɪndid mɑɹtʃ wɪð spid; ðeɪ wɝ plænɪŋ tə teɪk dɑɹlunə kwɪkli. ðeɪ sɔ ði ædvæntɪdʒ ɪt wəɾ ɔfɝ, fəɹ ðeɪ wɝ ə klɛvɝ foʊ, ən ðeɪ hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ɪɾɝɑldi ən ɪksaɪtmən i hæɾ əsum ðət hid lɛf bɪhaɪn jɪɹz əɡoʊ.

Ituralde raised his looking glass again, thinking on Lidrin's comment. The Seanchan did indeed march with speed; they were planning to take Darluna quickly. They saw the advantage it would offer, for they were a clever foe, and they had returned to Ituralde an excitement he had assumed that he'd left behind years ago.

"jɛs, ðeɪ pʊʃ hɑɹd," hi sɛd. "bʌt wʌt wəd jə du, lɪdʒɹɪn? ən ɛnəmi fɔɹs ə tu hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən bɪhaɪn ju, ənʌðɝ ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti θaʊzən əhɛɾ ə ju. wɪð ɛnəmiz ɑn ɔl saɪdz, wəd jə mɑɹtʃ jəɹ mɛn meɪbi dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl tu hɑɹɾ ɪf jə nu ðət jud faɪn ɹɛfjudʒ ət ði ɛnd?"

"Yes, they push hard," he said. "But what would you do, Lidrin? An enemy force of two hundred thousand behind you, another of a hundred and fifty thousand ahead of you. With enemies on all sides, would you march your men maybe just a little too hard if you knew that you'd find refuge at the end?"

lɪdʒɹɪn dɪd nɑt ɹɪspɑnd. ɪɾɝɑldi tɝn ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ spɹɪŋ filz klʌstɝd wɪð wɝkɝz ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ plæntɪŋ. dɑɹlunə wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾi fəɹ ðiz pɑɹts. nʌθɪŋ hɪɹ ɪn ðə wɛs kəd mætʃ ðə ɡɹæn sɪɾiz ə ði ist ən saʊθ, ʌv kɔɹs, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ʌv wʌt pipəl fɹəm tæntʃəkoʊ əɹ fɑlm wəd laɪk tə kleɪm. stɪl, dɑɹlunə hæɾ ə stɝɾi ɡɹænət wɔl ə ɡʊd twɛnti fit tɔl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bjuɾi tə ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən, bʌt ðə wɔl wɑz sɑləd, ən ɪt ɹæpt ə sɪɾi bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛni kʌntʃɹi bɔɪ ɡɔk. ɪn ɪz juθ, ɪɾɝɑldi wʊɾə kɔld ɪt ɡɹænd. ðət wɑz bɪfɔɹ hid ɡɔn tə faɪt ði il ət tɑɹ vəlɑn.

Lidrin did not respond. Ituralde turned his looking glass, examining spring fields clustered with workers going about their planting. Darluna was a large city for these parts. Nothing here in the west could match the grand cities of the east and south, of course, regardless of what people from Tanchico or Falme would like to claim. Still, Darluna had a sturdy granite wall a good twenty feet tall. There was no beauty to the fortification, but the wall was solid, and it wrapped a city big enough to make any country boy gawk. In his youth, Ituralde would have called it grand. That was before he'd gone to fight the Aiel at Tar Valon.

iðɝ weɪ, ɪt wɑz ðə bɛs fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən tə bi faʊn ɪn ði ɛɹiə, ən ðə sintʃæn kəmændɝz noʊ daʊt nu ɪt. ðeɪ cʊɾə tʃoʊzən tə hʌŋkɝ daʊn ɑn ə hɪltɑp; faɪɾɪŋ sɝaʊndəd wəd meɪk fʊl jus ə ðoʊz deɪmeɪn. haʊɛvɝ, ðət wəd nɑɾ oʊnli liv noʊ ɹitʃɹit, bʌt wəd liv əm mɪnəməl ɑpɝtunəɾiz fəɹ səplaɪ. ə sɪɾi wəɾ əv wɛlz ən pɝhæps lɛftoʊvɝ wɪntɝ stɔɹz ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔl. ən dɑɹlunə, wɪtʃ hæd hæɾ ɪts ɡæɹɪsənz pɹɛst ɪndə sɝvəs ɛlswɛɹ, wɑz fɑɹ tu smɔl tə ɔfɝ sɪɹiəs ɹɪzɪstəns. . . .

Either way, it was the best fortification to be found in the area, and the Seanchan commanders no doubt knew it. They could have chosen to hunker down on a hilltop; fighting surrounded would make full use of those damane. However, that would not only leave no retreat, but would leave them minimal opportunities for supply. A city would have wells and perhaps leftover winter stores inside the wall. And Darluna, which had had its garrisons pressed into service elsewhere, was far too small to offer serious resistance. . . .

ɪɾɝɑldi loʊɝɾ ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. hi dɪdnt niɾ ɪt tə noʊ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ əz ðə sintʃæn skaʊts ɹitʃt ðə sɪɾi, dɪmændɪŋ ðət ðə ɡeɪts bi oʊpən tə ði ɪnveɪɾɪŋ fɔɹs. hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, weɪɾɪŋ.

Ituralde lowered his looking glass. He didn't need it to know what was happening as the Seanchan scouts reached the city, demanding that the gates be opened to the invading force. He closed his eyes, waiting.

lɪdʒɹɪn ɛksheɪl sɔfli bɪsaɪd hɪm. "ðeɪ dɪdnt noʊɾəs," hi wɪspɝd. "ðeɪɹ muvɪŋ ðə bʌlk ə ðɛɹ fɔɹsɪz ʌp tə ðə wɔlz, weɪɾɪŋ tə bi lɛɾ ɪn!"

Lidrin exhaled softly beside him. "They didn't notice," he whispered. "They're moving the bulk of their forces up to the walls, waiting to be let in!"

"ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, oʊpənɪŋ ɪz aɪz. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn pɹɑbləm wɪð supɪɹiɝ skaʊts laɪk ðə ɹeɪkən. wən jə hæɾ æksɛs tə ə tul soʊ jusfəl, jə tɛndəd tə ɹɪlaɪ əpɑn ɪt. ən ɹɪlaɪəns laɪk ðət kəd bi ɛksplɔɪɾəd.

"Give the order," Ituralde said, opening his eyes. There was one problem with superior scouts like the raken. When you had access to a tool so useful, you tended to rely upon it. And reliance like that could be exploited.

ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ðə "fɑɹmɝz" ɑn ðə filz tɔst əsaɪd ðɛɹ tulz ən pʊl baʊz fɹəm hɪɾən klɛfs ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə ɡeɪts tə ðə sɪɾi oʊpənd, ɹɪvilɪŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz haɪɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd - soʊlʒɝz ðət ðə sintʃæn ɹeɪkən skaʊts hæd kleɪmd wɝ ə fɔɹ-deɪ ɹaɪɾ əweɪ.

In the distance, the "farmers" on the fields tossed aside their tools and pulled bows from hidden clefts in the ground. The gates to the city opened, revealing the soldiers hiding inside - soldiers that the Seanchan raken scouts had claimed were a four-day ride away.

ɪɾɝɑldi ɹeɪzd ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. ðə bæɾəl bɪɡæn.

Ituralde raised his looking glass. The battle began.

ðə pɹɑfəts fɪŋɡɝz bɪt dɝt, tɛɹɪŋ tʃɹɛntʃɪz ɪn ðə sɔɪl əz i skɹæmbəld ʌp tə ðə tɑp ə ðə fɔɹəstəd hɪlsaɪd. hɪz fɑloʊɝz stʃɹæɡəl bɪhaɪnd. soʊ fju. soʊ fju! bʌɾ i wəd ɹibɪld. ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn fɑloʊd hɪm, ən noʊ mæɾɝ wɛɹ i wɛnt, hi faʊnd wɪlɪŋ soʊlz. ðoʊz wɪð hɑɹts ðət wɝ pjʊɹ, ðoʊz u hæd hænz ðət bɝn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə ʃædoʊ.

The Prophet's fingers bit dirt, tearing trenches in the soil as he scrambled up to the top of the forested hillside. His followers straggled behind. So few. So few! But he would rebuild. The glory of the Dragon Reborn followed him, and no matter where he went, he found willing souls. Those with hearts that were pure, those who had hands that burned to destroy the Shadow.

jɛs! θɪŋk nɑɾ ə ðə pæst, θɪŋk ə ðə fjutʃɝ, wən ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wəd ɹul ɔl ə ðə lænd!

Yes! Think not of the past, think of the future, when the Lord Dragon would rule all of the land!

wən mɛn wəd bi sʌbʒɪkt oʊnli tə hɪm, ən tə hɪz pɹɑfət bɪniθ hɪm. ðoʊz deɪz wəd bi ɡlɔɹiəs ɪndid, deɪz wən nʌn wəd dɛɹ skɔɹn ðə pɹɑfəɾ əɹ dɪnaɪ hɪz wɪl. deɪz wən ðə pɹɑfət wʊdn əv tə sʌfɝ ði ɪndɪɡnəɾi ʌv lɪvɪŋ nɪɹ ðə vɛɹi kæmp - ðə vɛɹi wʌn - əz ʃæɾoʊzpɔn laɪk ðət kɹitʃɝ eɪbɑɹə. ɡlɔɹiəs deɪz. ɡlɔɹiəs deɪz wɝ kʌmɪŋ.

When men would be subject only to him, and to his Prophet beneath him. Those days would be glorious indeed, days when none would dare scorn the Prophet or deny his will. Days when the Prophet wouldn't have to suffer the indignity of living near the very camp - the very one - as Shadowspawn like that creature Aybara. Glorious days. Glorious days were coming.

ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə kip ɪz θɔts ɑn ðoʊz fjutʃɝ ɡlɔɹiz. ðə wɝld ɝaʊn ɪm wɑz fɪlθi. mɛn dɪnaɪd ðə dʒɹæɡən ən sɔt ðə ʃædoʊ. ivən ɪz oʊn fɑloʊɝz. jɛs! ðət mʌst əv bɪn waɪ ðeɪ hæd fɔlən. ðət mʌst əv bɪn waɪ soʊ mɛni daɪd wən əsɔltɪŋ ðə sɪɾi ʌv mɔldən ən ɪts dɑɹkfɹɛn il.

It was difficult to keep his thoughts on those future glories. The world around him was filthy. Men denied the Dragon and sought the Shadow. Even his own followers. Yes! That must have been why they had fallen. That must have been why so many died when assaulting the city of Malden and its Darkfriend Aiel.

ðə pɹɑfət hæd bɪn soʊ sɝɾən. hi hæɾ əsum ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən wəd pɹətɛkt ɪz pipəl, lɛɾ əm tə ə paʊɝfəl vɪktɝi. ðən ðə pɹɑfət wəd faɪnəli hæv ɡɑɾən ɪz wɪʃ. hi cʊɾə kɪl pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə wɪð ɪz oʊn hænz! twɪs ðət tu-θɪk bʊlz nɛk ɪn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, twɪst ɪɾ ɝaʊnd, skwizɪŋ, filɪŋ ðə boʊnz kɹæk, ðə flɛʃ ɹɪŋ, ðə bɹɛθ stɑp.

The Prophet had been so certain. He had assumed that the Dragon would protect his people, lead them to a powerful victory. Then the Prophet would finally have gotten his wish. He could have killed Perrin Aybara with his own hands! Twist that too-thick bull's neck in his fingers, twist it around, squeezing, feeling the bones crack, the flesh wring, the breath stop.

ðə pɹɑfət ɹitʃt ðə tɑp ə ðə ɹɪdʒ ən bɹʌʃt ðə dɝt fɹəm ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. hi bɹiðd ɪn ən aʊt, skænɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm, ʌndɝbɹʌʃ ɹʌslɪŋ əz ɪz fju ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ fɑloʊɝz klaɪmd ʌp təwɔɹd hɪm.

The Prophet reached the top of the ridge and brushed the dirt from his fingers. He breathed in and out, scanning around him, underbrush rustling as his few remaining followers climbed up toward him.

ðə kænəpi wɑz dɛns oʊvɝhɛd, ən vɛɹi lɪɾəl sʌnlaɪt pik θɹu. laɪt. ɹeɪɾiənt laɪt.

The canopy was dense overhead, and very little sunlight peeked through. Light. Radiant light.

ðə dʒɹæɡən hæɾ əpɪɹd tə hɪm ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ ði ətæk. əpɪɹɾ ɪn ɡlɔɹi! ə fɪɡjɝ ə laɪt, ɡloʊɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ ɪn ʃɪmɝɪŋ ɹoʊbz. kɪl pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə! ðə dʒɹæɡən hæd kəmændəd. kɪl hɪm!

The Dragon had appeared to him the night before the attack. Appeared in glory! A figure of light, glowing in the air in shimmering robes. Kill Perrin Aybara! the Dragon had commanded. Kill him!

ən soʊ ðə pɹɑfət hæd sɛn ɪz vɛɹi bɛs tul, eɪbɑɹəz oʊn dɪɹ fɹɛnd.

And so the Prophet had sent his very best tool, Aybara's own dear friend.

ðət bɔɪ, ðət tul, hæd feɪld. ɛɹæm wɑz dɛd. ðə pɹɑfəts mɛn hæd kənfɝmd ɪt. tʃɹædʒəɾi!

That boy, that tool, had failed. Aram was dead. The Prophet's men had confirmed it. Tragedy!

wɑz ðət waɪ ðeɪ hæd nɑt pɹɑspɝd? wɑz ðət waɪ, aʊɾ ə hɪz θaʊzənz ə fɑloʊɝz, hi naʊ oʊnli hæɾ ə bɛɹ hændfʊl? noʊ. noʊ! ðeɪ mʌst əv tɝn əɡɛns hɪm, sikɹɪtli wɝʃəpɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ.

Was that why they had not prospered? Was that why, out of his thousands of followers, he now only had a bare handful? No. No! They must have turned against him, secretly worshipping the Shadow.

ɛɹæm! dɑɹkfɹɛnd! ðət wɑz waɪ hi hæd feɪld.

Aram! Darkfriend! That was why he had failed.

ðə fɝst ə hɪz fɑloʊɝz - bæɾɝd, dɝɾid, blʌɾid, ɪɡzɔstəd - ɹitʃt ðə tɑp ə ðə ɹɪdʒ.

The first of his followers - battered, dirtied, bloodied, exhausted - reached the top of the ridge.

ðeɪ wɔɹ θɹɛdbɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ. kloʊðɪŋ ðət dɪd nɑt sɛɾ əm əbʌv ʌðɝz. ðə kloʊðɪŋ ə sɪmplɪsəɾi ən ɡʊdnəs.

They wore threadbare clothing. Clothing that did not set them above others. The clothing of simplicity and goodness.

ðə pɹɑfət kaʊntəɾ əm ɔf. fjuɝ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd. soʊ fju. ðɪs kɝs fɔɹəst wɑz soʊ dɑɹk, dɪspaɪt ðə deɪlaɪt. θɪk tʃɹʌŋks stʊd ʃoʊldɝ-tə-ʃoʊldɝ, ən ðə skaɪ oʊvɝhɛd hæd ɡɹoʊn dɪm wɪð klaʊd kʌvɝ. ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ ə θɪn-bɹæntʃt boʊnwid ʃɹʌbz mæɾɪd təɡɛðɝ, fɔɹmɪŋ ən ɔlmoʊst ənnætʃɹəl bæɹiɝ, ən ðoʊz ʃɹʌbz skɹætʃt laɪk klɔz ɑn ɪz skɪn.

The Prophet counted them off. Fewer than a hundred. So few. This cursed forest was so dark, despite the daylight. Thick trunks stood shoulder-to-shoulder, and the sky overhead had grown dim with cloud cover. The underbrush of thin-branched boneweed shrubs matted together, forming an almost unnatural barrier, and those shrubs scratched like claws on his skin.

wɪð ðəɾ ʌndɝbɹʌʃ ən ðə ʃɑɹp ɝθən bæŋk, ði ɑɹmi kəd nɑt fɑloʊ ðɪs weɪ. ðoʊ ðə pɹɑfət hæɾ ɪskeɪp fɹəm eɪbɑɹəz kæmp bɛɹli ən aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ, hi ɔlɹɛɾi fɛl seɪf. ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ nɔɹθ, wɛɹ eɪbɑɹə ən ɪz dɑɹkfɹɛnz wəd nɑt faɪn ðɛm. ðɛɹ, ðə pɹɑfət kəd ɹibɪld. hi hæd steɪd wɪð eɪbɑɹə oʊnli kəz ɪz fɑloʊɝz hæd bɪn stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə kip eɪbɑɹəz dɑɹkfɹɛnz əweɪ.

With that underbrush and the sharp earthen bank, the army could not follow this way. Though the Prophet had escaped from Aybara's camp barely an hour before, he already felt safe. They would go north, where Aybara and his Darkfriends would not find them. There, the Prophet could rebuild. He had stayed with Aybara only because his followers had been strong enough to keep Aybara's Darkfriends away.

hɪz dɪɹ fɑloʊɝz. bɹeɪv mɛn, ən tʃɹu, ɛvɹi wʌn. kɪl baɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. hi mɔɹn ðɛm, boʊɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ ə pɹɛɹ. hɪz fɑloʊɝz dʒɔɪn hɪm. ðeɪ wɝ wɪɹi, bʌt ðə laɪɾ ə zil ʃoʊn ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. ɛni hu wɝ wik, əɹ u læk dɛɾəkeɪʃən, hæd flɛɾ əɹ bɪn kɪld lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ðiz wɝ ðə bɛst, ðə maɪɾiəst, ðə moʊs feɪθfəl. itʃ wʌn hæd kɪl mɛni dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

His dear followers. Brave men, and true, every one. Killed by Darkfriends. He mourned them, bowing his head and muttering a prayer. His followers joined him. They were weary, but the light of zeal shone in their eyes. Any who were weak, or who lacked dedication, had fled or been killed long ago. These were the best, the mightiest, the most faithful. Each one had killed many Darkfriends in the name of the Dragon Reborn.

wɪð ðɛm, hi kəd ɹibɪld. bʌt fɝst i hæd tə ɪskeɪp eɪbɑɹə. ðə pɹɑfət wɑz tu wik, naʊ, tə feɪs hɪm. bʌt leɪɾɝ i wəd kɪl hɪm. jɛs . . . fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðət nɛk . . . jɛs . . .

With them, he could rebuild. But first he had to escape Aybara. The Prophet was too weak, now, to face him. But later he would kill him. Yes . . . Fingers on that neck . . . Yes . . .

ðə pɹɑfət kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ə taɪm wən hid bɪn kɔl sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. mæsimə. ðoʊz deɪz wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ vɛɹi blɝi tə hɪm, laɪk mɛmɹiz fɹəm ə fɔɹmɝ laɪf. ɪndid, dʒʌst əz ɔl mɛn wɝ ɹibɔɹn ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn, soʊ hæd mæsimə bɪn ɹibɔɹn - hi hæd kæst ɔf ɪz oʊld, pɹoʊfeɪn laɪf ən hæd bɪkʌm ðə pɹɑfət.

The Prophet could remember a time when he'd been called something else. Masema. Those days were growing very blurry to him, like memories from a former life. Indeed, just as all men were reborn into the Pattern, so had Masema been reborn - he had cast off his old, profane life and had become the Prophet.

ðə læst ə hɪz fɑloʊɝz dʒɔɪn ɪm ətɑp ðə klɪf feɪs. hi spæɾ ət ðɛɹ fit. ðeɪ hæd feɪl hɪm.

The last of his followers joined him atop the cliff face. He spat at their feet. They had failed him.

kaʊɝdz. ðeɪ ʃʊɾə fɔt bɛɾɝ! hi ʃʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə wɪn ðət sɪɾi.

Cowards. They should have fought better! He should have been able to win that city.

hi tɝnd nɔɹθ ən pʊʃt ɪz weɪ fɔɹwɝd. ðɪs lændskeɪp wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ fəmɪljɝ tə hɪm, ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ laɪk ɪɾ ʌp ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðeɪ wəd klaɪm tə ðə haɪlənz, ðən kɹɔs oʊvɝ ən ɛntɝ ɑlməθ pleɪn. ðəɹ wɝ dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn ðɛɹ, fɑloʊɝz ə ðə pɹɑfət, ivən ɪf mɛni dɪdnt noʊ ʌv hɪm. ðəɹ i kəd ɹibɪl kwɪkli.

He turned north and pushed his way forward. This landscape was growing familiar to him, though they had nothing like it up in the Borderlands. They would climb to the highlands, then cross over and enter Almoth Plain. There were Dragonsworn there, followers of the Prophet, even if many didn't know of him. There he could rebuild quickly.

hi pʊʃt θɹu ə pætʃ ə ðə dɑɹk bɹʌʃ ən ɛntɝɾ ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ. hɪz mɛn fɑloʊd kwɪkli. ðeɪ wəd nid fud, sun, ən i wəɾ əv tə sɛn əm hʌntɪŋ. noʊ faɪɝz. ðeɪ kʊdn əfɔɹd tə əlɝt -  "həloʊ, mæsimə," ə kwaɪət vɔɪs sɛd.

He pushed through a patch of the dark brush and entered a small clearing. His men followed quickly. They would need food, soon, and he would have to send them hunting. No fires. They couldn't afford to alert -  "Hello, Masema," a quiet voice said.

hi hɪst, spɪnɪŋ, hɪz fɑloʊɝz bʌntʃɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪm ən pʊlɪŋ aʊt wɛpənz. sɔɹdz fəɹ sʌm, naɪvz, kɔɹɾɝstɑfs, ən ði əkeɪʒənəl pɑlɹm. ðə pɹɑfət skæn ðə dɪm æftɝnun klɪɹɪŋ, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə wʌn u hæd spoʊkən. hi faʊn əɹ stændɪŋ ɑn ə lɪɾəl aʊtkɹɑp ə ɹɑk ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, ə wʊmən wɪð ə pɹɑmənən sɑldəiən noʊz, slaɪtli tɪltəɾ aɪz, ən ʃoʊldɝ- lɛŋθ blæk hɛɹ. ʃi wɔɹ ɡɹin, wɪð skɝts dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ, hɝ ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ.

He hissed, spinning, his followers bunching around him and pulling out weapons. Swords for some, knives, quarterstaffs, and the occasional polearm. The Prophet scanned the dim afternoon clearing, searching for the one who had spoken. He found her standing on a little outcrop of rock a short distance away, a woman with a prominent Saldaean nose, slightly tilted eyes, and shoulder- length black hair. She wore green, with skirts divided for riding, her arms folded in front of her.

feɪl eɪbɑɹə, waɪf ə ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. "teɪk hɝ!" ðə pɹɑfət skɹimd, pɔɪntɪŋ. sɛvɹəl ə hɪz fɑloʊɝz skɹæmbəl fɔɹwɝd, bʌt moʊs hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðeɪ hæd sin wʌɾ i hæd nɑt. ʃædoʊz ɪn ðə fɔɹəs bɪhaɪn eɪbɑɹəz waɪf, ə hæf-sɝkəl ə ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ ðə ʃeɪps ə mɛn, wɪð baʊz pɔɪntəɾ ɪndə ðə klɪɹɪŋ.

Faile Aybara, wife of the Shadowspawn, Perrin Aybara. "Take her!" the Prophet screamed, pointing. Several of his followers scrambled forward, but most hesitated. They had seen what he had not. Shadows in the forest behind Aybara's wife, a half-circle of them. They were the shapes of men, with bows pointed into the clearing.

feɪl weɪvd wɪð ə ʃɑɹp moʊʃən, ən ði æɹoʊz flu. ðoʊz ə hɪz fɑloʊɝz u hæd ɹʌn əɾ ɪz bɪɾɪŋ fɛl fɝst, kɹaɪɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ðə saɪlən fɔɹəs bɪfɔɹ fɔlɪŋ tə ðə loʊmi ɝθ. ðə pɹɑfət bɛloʊd, itʃ æɹoʊ simɪŋ tə pɪɹs ɪz oʊn hɑɹt. hɪz bɪlʌv fɑloʊɝz! hɪz fɹɛnz! hɪz dɪɹ bɹʌðɝz!

Faile waved with a sharp motion, and the arrows flew. Those of his followers who had run at his bidding fell first, crying out in the silent forest before falling to the loamy earth. The Prophet bellowed, each arrow seeming to pierce his own heart. His beloved followers! His friends! His dear brothers!

ən æɹoʊ slæmd ɪndə hɪm, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪm bækwɝd tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɝaʊn hɪm, mɛn daɪd, dʒʌst əz ðeɪ hæɾ ɝliɝ. waɪ, waɪ hædn ðə dʒɹæɡən pɹətɛktəd ðɛm? waɪ? sʌɾənli, ðə hɔɹɝ ʌv ɪɾ ɔl ɹɪtɝn tə hɪm, ðə sɪŋkɪŋ tɛɹɝ ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ ɪz mɛn fɔl ɪn weɪvz, ət wɑtʃɪŋ əm daɪ ət ðə hænz ə ðoʊz dɑɹkfɹɛn il.

An arrow slammed into him, throwing him backward to the ground. Around him, men died, just as they had earlier. Why, why hadn't the Dragon protected them? Why? Suddenly, the horror of it all returned to him, the sinking terror of watching his men fall in waves, at watching them die at the hands of those Darkfriend Aiel.

ɪt wɑz pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹəz fɔlt. ɪf oʊnli ðə pɹɑfət hæd sin ɝliɝ, bæk ɪn ði ɝli deɪz, bɪfɔɹ hiɾ ivən ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən fəɹ u hi wɑz!

It was Perrin Aybara's fault. If only the Prophet had seen earlier, back in the early days, before he'd even recognized the Lord Dragon for who he was!

"ɪts maɪ fɔlt," ðə pɹɑfət wɪspɝɾ əz ðə læst ə hɪz fɑloʊɝz daɪd. ɪt hæd teɪkən sɛvɹəl æɹoʊz tə stɑp səm ə ðɛm. ðət meɪɾ ɪm pɹaʊd.

"It's my fault," the Prophet whispered as the last of his followers died. It had taken several arrows to stop some of them. That made him proud.

sloʊli, hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf bæk tə hɪz fit, hæn tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ, wɛɹ ðə ʃæf spɹaʊɾəd. hid lɔs tu mʌtʃ blʌd. dɪzi, hi fɛl tə hɪz niz.

Slowly, he forced himself back to his feet, hand to his shoulder, where the shaft sprouted. He'd lost too much blood. Dizzy, he fell to his knees.

feɪl stɛp daʊn ɔf əɹ stoʊn ən ɛntɝd ðə klɪɹɪŋ. tu wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ tʃɹaʊzɝz fɑloʊd. ðeɪ lʊkt kənsɝnd, bʌt feɪl ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛɹ pɹoʊɾɛsts ðət ʃi steɪ bæk. ʃi wɔkt ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðə pɹɑfət, ðən slɪɾ əɹ naɪf fɹəm əɹ bɛlt. ɪt wɑz ə faɪn bleɪd, wɪð ə kæs hɪl ðət ʃoʊɾ ə wʊlfs hɛd. ðət wɑz wɛl. lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt, ðə pɹɑfət ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə deɪ wən hiɾ ɝn ɪz oʊn bleɪd. ðə deɪ hɪz fɑðɝ hæd ɡɪvən ɪt tə hɪm.

Faile stepped down off her stone and entered the clearing. Two women wearing trousers followed. They looked concerned, but Faile ignored their protests that she stay back. She walked right up to the Prophet, then slid her knife from her belt. It was a fine blade, with a cast hilt that showed a wolf's head. That was well. Looking at it, the Prophet remembered the day when he'd earned his own blade. The day his father had given it to him.

"θæŋk jə fəɹ hɛlpɪŋ tə əsɔl mɔldən, mæsimə," feɪl sɛd, stɑpɪŋ ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm.

"Thank you for helping to assault Malden, Masema," Faile said, stopping right in front of him.

ðən ʃi ɹitʃt ʌp ən ɹæm ðət naɪf ɪndə hɪz hɑɹt. hi fɛl bækwɝd, hɪz oʊn blʌd hɑɾ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst.

Then she reached up and rammed that knife into his heart. He fell backward, his own blood hot on his chest.

"səmtaɪmz, ə waɪf mʌs də wʌɾ əɹ hʌzbən kænɑt," hi hɝd feɪl tɛl əɹ wɪmən əz ɪz aɪz flʌɾɝd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kloʊz. "ɪɾ ɪz ə dɑɹk θɪŋ wi dɪd ðɪs deɪ, bʌt nɛsəsɛɹi. lɛt noʊ wʌn spik ʌv ɪt tə maɪ hʌzbənd. hi mʌs nɛvɝ noʊ."

"Sometimes, a wife must do what her husband cannot," he heard Faile tell her women as his eyes fluttered, trying to close. "It is a dark thing we did this day, but necessary. Let no one speak of it to my husband. He must never know."

hɝ vɔɪs ɡɹu dɪstənt. ðə pɹɑfət fɛl.

Her voice grew distant. The Prophet fell.

mæsimə. ðət hæd bɪn ɪz neɪm. hiɾ ɝn ɪz sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz fɪftinθ bɝθdeɪ. hɪz fɑðɝ hæd bɪn soʊ pɹaʊd.

Masema. That had been his name. He'd earned his sword on his fifteenth birthday. His father had been so proud.

ɪts oʊvɝ, ðɛn, hi θɔt, əneɪbəl tə kip ɪz aɪz oʊpən. hi kloʊz ðɛm, fɔlɪŋ əz ɪf θɹu ən ɛnləs vɔɪd. dɪɾ aɪ də wɛl, fɑðɝ, əɹ dɪɾ aɪ feɪl?

It's over, then, he thought, unable to keep his eyes open. He closed them, falling as if through an endless void. Did I do well, Father, or did I fail?

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ænsɝ. ən i dʒɔɪnd wɪð ðə vɔɪd, tʌmbəlɪŋ ɪndə ən ɛnləs si ʌv blæknəs.

There was no answer. And he joined with the void, tumbling into an endless sea of blackness.

tʃæptɝ wʌn

CHAPTER 1

tɪɹz fɹəm stil ðə wil ə taɪm tɝnz, ən eɪdʒəz kʌm ən pæs, livɪŋ mɛmɹiz ðət bɪkʌm lɛdʒənd. lɛdʒən feɪdz tə mɪθ, ən ivən mɪθ ɪz lɔŋ fɝɡɑɾən wən ði eɪdʒ ðət ɡeɪv ɪt bɝθ kʌmz əɡɛn. ɪn wʌn eɪdʒ, kɔl ðə θɝɾ eɪdʒ baɪ sʌm, ən eɪdʒ jɛt tə kʌm, ən eɪdʒ lɔŋ pæst, ə wɪn ɹoʊz ɝaʊn ði æləbæstɝ spaɪɹ noʊn əz ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðə wɪnd wɑz nɑt ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ niðɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋz nɔɹ ɛndɪŋz tə ðə tɝnɪŋ ə ðə wil ə taɪm. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

Tears from Steel The Wheel of Time turns, and Ages come and pass, leaving memories that become legend. Legend fades to myth, and even myth is long forgotten when the Age that gave it birth comes again. In one Age, called the Third Age by some, an Age yet to come, an Age long past, a wind rose around the alabaster spire known as the White Tower. The wind was not the beginning. There are neither beginnings nor endings to the turning of the Wheel of Time. But it was a beginning.

ðə wɪn twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn ðə mæɡnɪfəsən taʊɝ, bɹʌʃɪŋ pɝfəkli fɪɾəd stoʊnz ən flæpɪŋ mədʒɛstɪk bænɝz. ðə stʃɹʌktʃɝ wɑz sʌmhaʊ boʊθ ɡɹeɪsfəl ən paʊɝfəl ət ðə seɪm taɪm; ə mɛɾəfɔɹ, pɝhæps, fəɹ ðoʊz u hæɾ ɪnhæbəɾəd ɪt fəɹ oʊvɝ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz. fju lʊkɪŋ əpɑn ðə taʊɝ wəd ɡɛs ðəɾ əɾ ɪts hɑɹt, ɪt hæd bɪn boʊθ bɹoʊkən ən kɝʌptɪd. sɛpɝətli.

The wind twisted around the magnificent Tower, brushing perfectly fitted stones and flapping majestic banners. The structure was somehow both graceful and powerful at the same time; a metaphor, perhaps, for those who had inhabited it for over three thousand years. Few looking upon the Tower would guess that at its heart, it had been both broken and corrupted. Separately.

ðə wɪn blu, pæsɪŋ θɹu ə sɪɾi ðət simd mɔɹ ə wɝk ʌv ɑɹt ðən ə wɝkədeɪ kæpəɾəl.

The wind blew, passing through a city that seemed more a work of art than a workaday capital.

itʃ bɪldɪŋ wɑz ə mɑɹvəl; ivən ðə sɪmpəl ɡɹænət ʃoʊpfɹʌns hæd bɪn kɹæftɪd baɪ mətɪkjələs oʊɡiɝ hænz tə ɪvoʊk wʌndɝ ən bjuɾi. hɪɹ ə doʊm hɪntəɾ ət ðə fɔɹm ʌv ə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn. ðəɹ ə faʊntən spɹæŋ fɹəm ðə tɑp ʌv ə bɪldɪŋ ɪtsɛlf, kɹɛstɪŋ wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi tu weɪvz kɹæʃɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. ɑn wʌn kɑbəl stʃɹit, ə pɛɹ ə stip θɹi-stɔɹi bɪldɪŋz stʊɾ ɑpəzət wʌn ənʌðɝ, itʃ kɹæftɪɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹm ʌv ə meɪɾən. ðə mɑɹbəl kɹieɪʃənz - hæf-stætʃu, hæf-dwɛlɪŋ - ɹitʃt wɪð stoʊn hænz təwɔɹd wʌn ənʌðɝ əz ɪf ɪn ɡɹiɾɪŋ, hɛɹ bɪloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, ɪmoʊbəl, jɛt kɑɹvd wɪð sətʃ dɛləkəsi ðəɾ ɛvɹi stʃɹæn sim tə ənʒəleɪt ɪn ðə wɪnz pæsɪŋ.

Each building was a marvel; even the simple granite shopfronts had been crafted by meticulous Ogier hands to evoke wonder and beauty. Here a dome hinted at the form of a rising sun. There a fountain sprang from the top of a building itself, cresting what appeared to be two waves crashing together. On one cobbled street, a pair of steep three-story buildings stood opposite one another, each crafted into the form of a maiden. The marble creations - half-statue, half-dwelling - reached with stone hands toward one another as if in greeting, hair billowing behind, immobile, yet carved with such delicacy that every strand seemed to undulate in the wind's passing.

ðə stʃɹits ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ fɑɹ lɛs ɡɹænd. oʊ, ðeɪ hæd bɪn leɪɾ aʊt wɪð kɛɹ, ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ laɪk stʃɹiks ə sʌnlaɪt. jɛt ðət sʌnlaɪt wɑz dɪm baɪ ɹɛfjus ən klʌɾɝ, hɪns ət ðə kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə sidʒ hæd kɑzd. ən pɝhæps ðə kɹaʊɾɪŋ wɑzn ði oʊnli ɹizən fəɹ ðə dɪsɹɪpɛɹ. ðə stɔɹfɹɑn saɪnz ən ɔnɪŋz hædn sin wɑʃ əɹ pɑlɪʃ ɪn fɑɹ tu lɔŋ. ɹɑɾɪŋ ɡɑɹbɪdʒ paɪld wɛɹ ɪt hæd bɪn dʌmpt ɪn æliz, dʒɹɔɪŋ flaɪz ən ɹæts bʌt dʒɹaɪvɪŋ əweɪ ɔl ʌðɝz.

The streets themselves were far less grand. Oh, they had been laid out with care, radiating from the White Tower like streaks of sunlight. Yet that sunlight was dimmed by refuse and clutter, hints at the crowding the siege had caused. And perhaps the crowding wasn't the only reason for the disrepair. The storefront signs and awnings hadn't seen wash or polish in far too long. Rotting garbage piled where it had been dumped in alleys, drawing flies and rats but driving away all others.

deɪnʒɝəs tʌfs laʊnʒd ɑn ðə stʃɹit kɔɹnɝz. wʌns, ðeɪd nɛvɝ əv dɛɹd də ðæt, ən sɝɾənli nɑt wɪð sətʃ ɛɹəɡəns.

Dangerous toughs lounged on the street corners. Once, they'd never have dared do that, and certainly not with such arrogance.

wɛɹ wɑz ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ðə lɔ? jʌŋ fulz læft, seɪɪŋ ðət ðə sɪɾiz tʃɹʌbəlz wɝ ðə fɔlt ə ðə sidʒ, ən ðət θɪŋz wəd sɛɾəl daʊn wʌns ðə ɹɛbəlz wɝ kwɛld. oʊldɝ mɛn ʃʊk ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik hɛdz ən mʌɾɝd ðət θɪŋz hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ðɪs bæd, ivən wən ðə sævədʒ il hæd bɪsidʒ tɑɹ vəlɑn səm twɛnti jɪɹz pɹiviəsli.

Where was the White Tower, the law? Young fools laughed, saying that the city's troubles were the fault of the siege, and that things would settle down once the rebels were quelled. Older men shook their gray-streaked heads and muttered that things had never been this bad, even when the savage Aiel had besieged Tar Valon some twenty years previously.

mɝtʃəns ɪɡnɔɹd boʊθ jʌŋ ən oʊld. ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ oʊn pɹɑbləmz, meɪnli ɑn saʊθhɑɹbɝ, wɛɹ tʃɹeɪɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi baɪ weɪ ʌv ðə ɹɪvɝ hæd nɪɹli kʌm tə ə hɔlt. θɪk-tʃɛstəd wɝkɝz tɔɪl bɪniθ ði aɪz ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛɹɪŋ ə ɹɛd-fɹɪnd ʃɔl; ʃi juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə ɹimuv wɔɹdz ən wikən ðə stoʊn, waɪl ðə wɝkmɪn bɹoʊk ðə ɹɑk əpɑɹɾ ən hɔld ɪɾ əweɪ.

Merchants ignored both young and old. They had their own problems, mainly on Southharbor, where trade into the city by way of the river had nearly come to a halt. Thick-chested workers toiled beneath the eyes of an Aes Sedai wearing a red-fringed shawl; she used the One Power to remove wards and weaken the stone, while the workmen broke the rock apart and hauled it away.

ðə wɝkmɪn hæd slivz ɹoʊld ʌp, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ kɝlz ə dɑɹk hɛɹ əlɔŋ bɝli ɑɹmz, əz ðeɪ swʌŋ pɪk əɹ hæmɝ, paʊndɪŋ ət ði eɪntʃən stoʊnz. ðeɪ dʒɹɪp swɛɾ ɑntu ɹɑk əɹ ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ bɪloʊ əz ðeɪ dʌɡ ət ðə ɹuts ə ðə tʃeɪn ðət blɑk pæsədʒ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi baɪ ɹɪvɝ. hæf ə ðət tʃeɪn wɑz naʊ ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl kwəndɪlɝ, kɔl hɑɹtstoʊn baɪ sʌm. ði ɛfɝt tə tɛɹ ɪt fɹi ən əlaʊ pæsədʒ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi wɑz ən ɪɡzɔstɪŋ wʌn; ðə hɑɹbɝ stoʊnwɝks - mæɡnɪfəsən ən stʃɹɔŋ, ʃeɪp baɪ ðə paʊɝ ɪtsɛlf - wɝ oʊnli wʌn ə ðə mɔɹ vɪzəbəl kæʒəwəltiz ə ðə saɪlənt wɔɹ bɪtwin ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðoʊz u hɛl ðə taʊɝ.

The workmen had sleeves rolled up, exposing curls of dark hair along burly arms, as they swung pick or hammer, pounding at the ancient stones. They dripped sweat onto rock or into the water below as they dug at the roots of the chain that blocked passage into the city by river. Half of that chain was now indestructible cuendillar, called heartstone by some. The effort to tear it free and allow passage into the city was an exhausting one; the harbor stoneworks - magnificent and strong, shaped by the Power itself - were only one of the more visible casualties of the silent war between the rebel Aes Sedai and those who held the Tower.

ðə wɪn blu θɹu ðə hɑɹbɝ, wɛɹ aɪɾəlɪŋ pɔɹɾɝz stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wɝkɝz tʃɪp ðə stoʊnz əweɪ, wʌn baɪ wʌn, sɛndɪŋ fleɪks ʌv ɡɹeɪ-waɪt dʌs tə floʊɾ ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ. ðoʊz wɪð tu mʌtʃ sɛns - əɹ pɝhæps tu lɪɾəl - wɪspɝd ðət sətʃ pɔɹtɛns kəd min oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ. tɑɹmən ɡdən, ðə læs bæɾəl, mʌs kwɪkli bi əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ.
