The wind blew through the harbor, where idling porters stood watching the workers chip the stones away, one by one, sending flakes of gray-white dust to float on the water. Those with too much sense - or perhaps too little - whispered that such portents could mean only one thing. Tarmon Gai'don, the Last Battle, must quickly be approaching.

ðə wɪn dænst əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɑks, pæsɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə tɔl waɪt bəlwɹks noʊn əz ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz. hɪɹ, ət list, wʌn kəd faɪn klɛnlinɪs ən ətɛnʃən ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾ u stʊd wɑtʃ, hoʊldɪŋ baʊz. klin-ʃeɪvən, wɛɹɪŋ waɪt tɑbɝdz fɹi fɹəm steɪn əɹ wɛɹ, ði ɑɹtʃɝz wɑtʃt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ bæɹəkeɪdz wɪð ðə deɪnʒɝəs ɹɛɾinəs ə sneɪks pɹipɛɹd tə stʃɹaɪk. ðiz soʊlʒɝz hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə lɛɾɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn fɔl waɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɑn duɾi. tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd ɹəpɛld ɛvɹi ɛnəmi.

The wind danced away from the docks, passing over the tall white bulwarks known as the Shining Walls. Here, at least, one could find cleanliness and attention in the Tower Guard who stood watch, holding bows. Clean-shaven, wearing white tabards free from stain or wear, the archers watched over their barricades with the dangerous readiness of snakes prepared to strike. These soldiers had no intention of letting Tar Valon fall while they were on duty. Tar Valon had repelled every enemy.

tʃɹɑləks hæd bɹitʃt ðə wɔlz, bʌt bɪn dɪfiɾəd ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ hæd feɪl tə teɪk tɑɹ vəlɑn. ivən ðə blæk-veɪld il, hu hæd ɹævɪdʒ ðə læn dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ, hæd nɛvɝ teɪkən ðə sɪɾi. mɛni kleɪm ðɪs əz ə ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝi. ʌðɝz wʌndɝd wʌt wʊɾə hæpən ɪf ði il hæɾ æktʃəli  wɑntəd tə kɹɔs ɪndə ðə sɪɾi.

Trollocs had breached the walls, but been defeated in the city. Artur Hawkwing had failed to take Tar Valon. Even the black-veiled Aiel, who had ravaged the land during the Aiel War, had never taken the city. Many claimed this as a great victory. Others wondered what would have happened if the Aiel had actually wanted to cross into the city.

ðə wɪn pæst oʊvɝ ðə wɛstɝn fɔɹk ə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn, livɪŋ ði aɪlən ə tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪhaɪnd, pæsɪŋ ði əlɪndɑɹ bɹɪdʒ sɔɹɪŋ haɪ tə ðə ɹaɪt, əz ɪf tɔntɪŋ ɛnəmiz tə kɹɔs ɪɾ ən daɪ. pæs ðə bɹɪdʒ, ðə wɪn swɛpt ɪndə əlɪndɑɹ, wʌn ə ðə mɛni vɪlədʒəz nɪɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪt wɑz ə vɪlədʒ moʊsli dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd, əz fæmliz hæd flɛɾ əkɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒ fəɹ ɹɛfjudʒ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ði ɛnəmi ɑɹmi hæɾ əpɪɹd sʌɾənli, wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ, əz ɪf bɹɔt baɪ ə blɪzɝd. fju wʌndɝɾ əɾ ɪt. ðɪs ɹɛbəl ɑɹmi wɑz hɛɾəd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðoʊz u lɪvd ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝz ʃædoʊ ɹɛɹli ɡæmbəld ɑn dʒʌst wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəɾ ən kʊdn du.

The wind passed over the western fork of the River Erinin, leaving the island of Tar Valon behind, passing the Alindaer Bridge soaring high to the right, as if taunting enemies to cross it and die. Past the bridge, the wind swept into Alindaer, one of the many villages near Tar Valon. It was a village mostly depopulated, as families had fled across the bridge for refuge in the city. The enemy army had appeared suddenly, without warning, as if brought by a blizzard. Few wondered at it. This rebel army was headed by Aes Sedai, and those who lived in the White Tower's shadow rarely gambled on just what Aes Sedai could and couldn't do.

ðə ɹɛbəl ɑɹmi wɑz pɔɪzd, bʌɾ ənsɝɾən. oʊvɝ fɪfti θaʊzən stʃɹɔŋ, ɪt kæmpt ɪn ə mæsɪv ɹɪŋ ə tɛns ɝaʊn ðə smɔlɝ kæmp ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪt pɝɪməɾɝ bɪtwin ði ɪnɝ kæmp ən ði aʊɾɝ wʌn, ə pɝɪməɾɝ ðət hæd moʊst ɹisənli bɪn ɪntɛndəd tə ɪksklud mɛn, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðoʊz u kəd wil seɪɾɪn.

The rebel army was poised, but uncertain. Over fifty thousand strong, it camped in a massive ring of tents around the smaller camp of Aes Sedai. There was a tight perimeter between the inner camp and the outer one, a perimeter that had most recently been intended to exclude men, particularly those who could wield saidin.

ɔlmoʊst, wʌn kəd θɪŋk ðət ðɪs kæmp ə ɹɛbəlz ɪntɛndəd tə sɛɾ ʌp pɝmənənli. ɪt hæɾ ən ɛɹ ə kɑmən deɪli laɪf əbaʊɾ ɪts wɝkɪŋz. fɪɡjɝz ɪn waɪt bʌsəld əbaʊt, səm wɛɹɪŋ fɔɹməl nɑvəs dʒɹɛsəz, mɛni ʌðɝz kloʊðd ɪn nɪɹ əpɹɑksəmeɪʃənz. lʊkɪŋ kloʊsli, wʌn kəd si ðət mɛni ʌv ðiz wɝ fɑɹ fɹəm jʌŋ. səm hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹitʃt ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪɪŋ. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɹəfɝd tə əz "tʃɪlʒɹən," ən oʊbiɾiənt ðeɪ wɝ əz ðeɪ wɑʃt kloʊðɪŋ, bit ɹʌɡz, ən skɹʌb tɛns bɪniθ ði aɪz ə sɝin-feɪst ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ɪf ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡlænst wɪð ənkɑmən fɹikwənsi ət ðə neɪl-laɪk pɹoʊfaɪl ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wʌn wəd bi mɪsteɪkən ɪn əsumɪŋ əm ənkʌmftəɹbəl əɹ nɝvəs. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. ɔlweɪz. ivən naʊ, wən ðeɪ hæd sʌfɝɾ ən ɪndɛlɪbəl dɪfit:

Almost, one could think that this camp of rebels intended to set up permanently. It had an air of common daily life about its workings. Figures in white bustled about, some wearing formal novice dresses, many others clothed in near approximations. Looking closely, one could see that many of these were far from young. Some had already reached their graying. But they were referred to as "children," and obedient they were as they washed clothing, beat rugs, and scrubbed tents beneath the eyes of serene-faced Aes Sedai. And if those Aes Sedai glanced with uncommon frequency at the nail-like profile of the White Tower, one would be mistaken in assuming them uncomfortable or nervous. Aes Sedai were in control. Always. Even now, when they had suffered an indelible defeat:

ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, ðə ɹɛbəl æmɪɝlɪn sit, hæd bɪn kæptʃɝɾ ən ɪmpɹɪzənd wɪðɪn ðə taʊɝ.

Egwene al'Vere, the rebel Amyrlin Seat, had been captured and imprisoned within the Tower.

ðə wɪn flɪkt ə fju dʒɹɛsəz, nɑk səm lɔnʒɹi fɹəm ɪts hæŋʒɪŋz, ðən kəntɪnjud wɛstwɝɾ ɪn ə ɹʌʃ. wɛstwɝd, pæs taʊɝɪŋ dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, wɪð ɪts ʃæɾɝd ən smoʊkɪŋ eɪpɛks.

The wind flicked a few dresses, knocked some laundry from its hangings, then continued westward in a rush. Westward, past towering Dragonmount, with its shattered and smoking apex.

oʊvɝ ðə blæk hɪlz ən əkɹɔs ðə swipɪŋ kæɹələn ɡɹæs. hɪɹ, pɑkəts ə ʃɛltɝd snoʊ klʌŋ tə ʃædoʊz bɪniθ kɹæɡi oʊvɝhæŋz əɹ bɪsaɪd ði əkeɪʒənəl stænz ə maʊntən blækwʊd. ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ spɹɪŋ tə ɝaɪv, taɪm fəɹ nu ʃuts tə pik θɹu ðə wɪntɝz θætʃ ən fəɹ bʌdz tə spɹaʊɾ ɑn ðə θɪn-bɹæntʃt wɪloʊz. fju ʌv iðɝ hæɾ æktʃəli  kʌm. ðə lænd wɑz stɪl dɔɹmənt, əz ɪf weɪɾɪŋ, hoʊldɪŋ ɪts bɹɛθ. ði ənnætʃɹəl hiɾ ə ðə pɹiviəs ɔɾəm hæd stʃɹɛtʃt wɛl ɪndə wɪntɝ, pɹɛsɪŋ əpɑn ðə læn ə dʒɹaʊt ðət hæd beɪk ðə laɪf fɹəm ɔl bʌt ðə moʊs vɪɡɝəs plæns.

Over the Black Hills and across the sweeping Caralain Grass. Here, pockets of sheltered snow clung to shadows beneath craggy overhangs or beside the occasional stands of mountain blackwood. It was time for spring to arrive, time for new shoots to peek through the winter's thatch and for buds to sprout on the thin-branched willows. Few of either had actually come. The land was still dormant, as if waiting, holding its breath. The unnatural heat of the previous autumn had stretched well into winter, pressing upon the land a drought that had baked the life from all but the most vigorous plants.

wən wɪntɝ hæd faɪnəli ɝaɪvd, ɪt hæd kʌm ɪn ə tɛmpəst ʌv aɪs ən snoʊ, ə lɪŋɡɝɪŋ, kɪlɪŋ fɹɔst.

When winter had finally arrived, it had come in a tempest of ice and snow, a lingering, killing frost.

naʊ ðət ðə koʊl hæd faɪnəli ɹitʃɹiɾəd, ðə skæɾɝd fɑɹmɝz lʊkt ɪn veɪn fəɹ hoʊp.

Now that the cold had finally retreated, the scattered farmers looked in vain for hope.

ðə wɪn swɛpt əkɹɔs bɹaʊn wɪntɝ ɡɹæs, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz' stɪl-bæɹən bɹæntʃəz. tə ðə wɛst, əz ɪɾ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə lænd noʊn əz ɑɹæd dumən - kɹɛstɪŋ hɪlz ən ʃɔɹt piks - sʌmθɪŋ sʌɾənli slæmd əɡɛnst ɪt. sʌmθɪŋ ənsin, sʌmθɪŋ spɔn baɪ ðə dɪstən dɑɹknəs tə ðə nɔɹθ. sʌmθɪŋ ðət floʊɾ əɡɛns ðə nætʃɹəl taɪɾ ən kɝəns ə ði ɛɹ. ðə wɪnd wɑz kənsum baɪ ɪt, bloʊn saʊθwɝɾ ɪn ə ɡʌst, əkɹɔs loʊ piks ən bɹaʊn fʊthɪlz tə ə lɔɡ mænɝ haʊs, aɪsəleɪɾəd, sɛɾ əpɑn ðə paɪn-fɔɹəstəd hɪlz ɪn istɝn ɑɹæd dumən. ðə wɪn blu əkɹɔs ðə mænɝ haʊs ən ðə tɛns sɛɾ ʌp ɪn ðə waɪd, oʊpən fil bɪfɔɹ ɪt, ɹætlɪŋ paɪn niɾəlz ən ʃeɪkɪŋ tɛns.

The wind swept across brown winter grass, shaking the trees' still-barren branches. To the west, as it approached the land known as Arad Doman - cresting hills and short peaks - something suddenly slammed against it. Something unseen, something spawned by the distant darkness to the north. Something that flowed against the natural tide and currents of the air. The wind was consumed by it, blown southward in a gust, across low peaks and brown foothills to a log manor house, isolated, set upon the pine-forested hills in eastern Arad Doman. The wind blew across the manor house and the tents set up in the wide, open field before it, rattling pine needles and shaking tents.

ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, stʊd, hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk əz i lʊkt aʊt ði oʊpən mænɝ wɪndoʊ. hi stɪl θɔɾ ə ðɛm ðət weɪ, hɪz "hænz," ðoʊ hi naʊ hæɾ oʊnli wʌn. hɪz lɛft ɑɹm ɛndəɾ ɪn ə stʌmp. hi kəd fil ðə smuð, seɪaɪdɑɹ-hil skɪn wɪð ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə hɪz ɡʊd hænd. jɛɾ i fɛlt əz ɪf ɪz ʌðɝ hænd ʃəd bi ðəɹ tə tʌtʃ.

Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn, stood, hands behind his back as he looked out the open manor window. He still thought of them that way, his "hands," though he now had only one. His left arm ended in a stump. He could feel the smooth, saidar-healed skin with the fingers of his good hand. Yet he felt as if his other hand should be there to touch.

stil, hi θɔt. aɪm stil. ðɪs kænɑt bi fɪkst, ən soʊ aɪ muv ɑn.

Steel, he thought. I am steel. This cannot be fixed, and so I move on.

ðə bɪldɪŋ - ə θɪk-lɔɡd stʃɹʌktʃɝ ə paɪn ən siɾɝ æftɝ ə dɪzaɪn feɪvɝd baɪ ðə dəmɑni wɛlθi - ɡɹoʊn ən sɛɾəld ɪn ðə wɪnd. sʌmθɪŋ ɑn ðət wɪn smɛld ə ɹɑɾən mit. nɑɾ ən ənkɑmən sɛnt, ðiz deɪz. mit spɔɪld wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ, səmtaɪmz oʊnli ə fju mɪnəts æftɝ bʊtʃɝɪŋ. dʒɹaɪɪŋ ɪɾ əɹ sɔltɪŋ ɪt dɪdn hɛlp. ɪt wɑz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ, ən ɪt ɡɹu wɪð itʃ pæsɪŋ deɪ. haʊ lɔŋ əntɪl ɪt wɑz əz oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ, əz ɔɪli ən nɔʒieɪɾɪŋ, əz ðə teɪn ðət hæd wʌns koʊɾəd seɪɾɪn, ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ?

The building - a thick-logged structure of pine and cedar after a design favored by the Domani wealthy - groaned and settled in the wind. Something on that wind smelled of rotten meat. Not an uncommon scent, these days. Meat spoiled without warning, sometimes only a few minutes after butchering. Drying it or salting it didn't help. It was the Dark One's touch, and it grew with each passing day. How long until it was as overwhelming, as oily and nauseating, as the taint that had once coated saidin, the male half of the One Power?

ðə ɹum i stʊɾ ɪn wɑz waɪɾ ən lɔŋ, θɪk lɔɡz meɪkɪŋ ʌp ði aʊɾɝ wɔl. plæŋks ə paɪn -  stɪl smɛlɪŋ feɪnli ʌv sæp ən steɪn - meɪɾ ʌp ði ʌðɝ wɔlz. ðə ɹum wɑz fɝnɪʃt spɑɹsli: fɝ ɹʌɡ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ə pɛɹ ʌv eɪdʒ kɹɔst sɔɹdz əbʌv ðə hɑɹθ, fɝnɪtʃɝ ʌv wʊd wɪð ðə bɑɹk lɛft ɑn ɪn pætʃəz. ði ɪntaɪɝ pleɪs hæd bɪn dɛkɝeɪɾəd ɪn ə weɪ tə seɪ ðət ðɪs wɑz ən aɪdɪlɪk hoʊm ɪn ðə wʊdz, əweɪ fɹəm ðə bʌsəl ə lɑɹdʒɝ sɪɾiz. nɑɾ ə kæbən, ʌv kɔɹs - ɪt wɑz fɑɹ tu lɑɹdʒ ən lævɪʃ fəɹ ðæt. ə ɹitʃɹit.

The room he stood in was wide and long, thick logs making up the outer wall. Planks of pine -  still smelling faintly of sap and stain - made up the other walls. The room was furnished sparsely: fur rug on the floor, a pair of aged crossed swords above the hearth, furniture of wood with the bark left on in patches. The entire place had been decorated in a way to say that this was an idyllic home in the woods, away from the bustle of larger cities. Not a cabin, of course - it was far too large and lavish for that. A retreat.

"ɹænd?" ə sɑf vɔɪs æskt. hi dɪdn tɝn, bʌt fɛl mɪnz fɪŋɡɝz tʌtʃ ɪz ɑɹm. ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, hɝ hænz muv tə hɪz weɪst ən i fɛlt əɹ hɛd ɹɛst əpɑn ɪz ɑɹm. hi kəd fil əɹ kənsɝn fəɹ ɪm θɹu ðə bɑn ðeɪ ʃɛɹd.

"Rand?" a soft voice asked. He didn't turn, but felt Min's fingers touch his arm. A moment later, her hands moved to his waist and he felt her head rest upon his arm. He could feel her concern for him through the bond they shared.

stil, hi θɔt.

Steel, he thought.

"aɪ noʊ jə doʊn laɪk - " mɪn bɪɡæn.

"I know you don't like - " Min began.

"ðə baʊz," hi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ. "ju si ðoʊz paɪnz, dʒʌs tə ðə saɪɾ ə bæʃɪɹz kæmp?"

"The boughs," he said, nodding out the window. "You see those pines, just to the side of Bashere's camp?"

"jɛs, ɹænd. bʌt - "

"Yes, Rand. But - "

"ðeɪ bloʊ ðə ɹɔŋ dɝɛkʃən," ɹænd sɛd.

"They blow the wrong direction," Rand said.

mɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən ðoʊ ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ fɪzɪkəl ɹiækʃən, ðə bɑn bɹɔɾ ɪm əɹ spaɪk ʌv əlɑɹm.

Min hesitated, and though she gave no physical reaction, the bond brought him her spike of alarm.

ðɛɹ wɪndoʊ wɑz ɑn ði ʌpɝ flɔɹ ə ðə mænɝ, ən aʊtsaɪɾ ʌv ɪt, bænɝz sɛɾ əbʌv ðə kæmp flæpt əɡɛns ðɛmsɛlvz: ðə bænɝ ə laɪɾ ən ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝ fəɹ ɹænd, ə mʌtʃ smɔlɝ blu flæɡ bɛɹɪŋ ðə θɹi ɹɛd kɪŋspɛni blɑsəmz tə mɑɹk ðə pɹɛzəns ə haʊs bæʃɪɹ. ɔl θɹi flu pɹaʊd . . . jɛt dʒʌs tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm, ðə niɾəlz ɑn ðə paɪnz blu ɪn ði ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃən.

Their window was on the upper floor of the manor, and outside of it, banners set above the camp flapped against themselves: the Banner of Light and the Dragon Banner for Rand, a much smaller blue flag bearing the three red kingspenny blossoms to mark the presence of House Bashere. All three flew proud . . . yet just to the side of them, the needles on the pines blew in the opposite direction.

"ðə dɑɹk wʌn stɝz, mɪn," ɹænd sɛd. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs θɪŋk ðiz wɪnz ə ɹɪzʌlt ə hɪz oʊn tɑvɝən neɪtʃɝ, bʌt ði ɪvɛns i kɑzd wɝ ɔlweɪz pɑsəbəl. ðə wɪn bloʊɪŋ ɪn tu dɝɛkʃənz ət wʌns . . . wɛl, hi kəd fil ðə ɹɔŋɡnəs ɪn ðə weɪ ðoʊz paɪnz muvd, ivən ɪf i dɪɾ əv tʃɹʌbəl dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃɪŋ ði ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl niɾəlz. hɪz aɪsaɪt hædn bɪn ðə seɪm sɪns ði ətæk ɑn ðət deɪ hid lɔst ɪz hænd. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf . . . əz ɪf i lʊk θɹu wɔɾɝ ət sʌmθɪŋ dɪstɔɹɾəd. ɪt wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ bɛɾɝ, sloʊli.

"The Dark One stirs, Min," Rand said. He could almost think these winds a result of his own ta'veren nature, but the events he caused were always possible. The wind blowing in two directions at once . . . well, he could feel the wrongness in the way those pines moved, even if he did have trouble distinguishing the individual needles. His eyesight hadn't been the same since the attack on that day he'd lost his hand. It was as if . . . as if he looked through water at something distorted. It was getting better, slowly.

ðɪs bɪldɪŋ wɑz wʌn ɪn ə lɔŋ laɪn ə mænɝz, ɪsteɪts ən ʌðɝ ɹɪmoʊt haɪɾɪŋ pleɪsəz ɹænd hæd juz dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs fju wiks. hid wɑntəd tə kip muvɪŋ, dʒʌmpɪŋ fɹəm loʊkeɪʃən tə loʊkeɪʃən, fɑloʊɪŋ ðə feɪl miɾɪŋ wɪð sɛmɝhɪdʒ. hid wɑntəd taɪm tə θɪŋk, tə kənsɪɾɝ, ən hoʊpfəli taɪm tə kənfjuz ði ɛnəmiz ðət maɪt bi sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. lɔɹɾ ælɡɝɪnz mænɝ ɪn tiɹ hæd bɪn kɑmpɹəmaɪzd; ə pɪɾi. ðət hæd bɪn ə ɡʊd pleɪs tə steɪ. bʌt ɹænd hæd tə kip muvɪŋ.

This building was one in a long line of manors, estates and other remote hiding places Rand had used during the last few weeks. He'd wanted to keep moving, jumping from location to location, following the failed meeting with Semirhage. He'd wanted time to think, to consider, and hopefully time to confuse the enemies that might be searching for him. Lord Algarin's manor in Tear had been compromised; a pity. That had been a good place to stay. But Rand had to keep moving.

bɪloʊ, bæʃɪɹz sɑldəiənz hæd sɛɾ ʌp ə kæmp ɑn ðə mænɝz ɡɹin - ði oʊpən pætʃ ʌv ɡɹæs aʊt fɹʌnt, baʊndəd baɪ ɹoʊz ə fɝ ən paɪn tʃɹiz. kɔlɪŋ ɪt ðə "ɡɹin" simd ən aɪɹəni, ðiz deɪz. ivən bɪfɔɹ ði ɑɹmiz ɝaɪvəl, ɪt hædn bɪn ɡɹin - ɪt hæd bɪn ə pætʃi bɹaʊn, wɪntɝ θætʃ bɹoʊkən oʊnli əkeɪʒənəli baɪ hɛzɪɾənt nu ʃuts. ðoʊz hæd bɪn sɪkli ən jɛloʊ, ən ðeɪ hæd naʊ bɪn tʃɹæmpəl baɪ hʊvz əɹ buɾɪd fit.

Below, Bashere's Saldaeans had set up a camp on the manor's green - the open patch of grass out front, bounded by rows of fir and pine trees. Calling it the "green" seemed an irony, these days. Even before the army's arrival, it hadn't been green - it had been a patchy brown, winter thatch broken only occasionally by hesitant new shoots. Those had been sickly and yellow, and they had now been trampled by hooves or booted feet.

tɛns kʌvɝd ðə ɡɹin. fɹəm ɹændz væntədʒ ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, ðə nit laɪnz ə smɔl, pik tɛns ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə skwɛɹz ɑn ə stoʊnz bɔɹd. ðə soʊlʒɝz hæd noʊɾəst ðə wɪnd. səm pɔɪntəd, ʌðɝz kɛp ðɛɹ hɛdz daʊn, pɑlɪʃɪŋ ɑɹmɝ, kæɹiɪŋ bʌkəts ʌv wɔɾɝ tə ðə hɔɹslaɪnz, ʃɑɹpənɪŋ sɔɹdz əɹ læns pɔɪns. ət list ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə dɛd wɔkɪŋ əɡɛn. ðə moʊs fɝm-hɑɹɾəd ə mɛn kəd luz ðɛɹ wɪl wən spɪɹəts ɹoʊz fɹəm ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪvz, ən ɹænd niɾəd ɪz ɑɹmi tə bi stʃɹɔŋ.

Tents covered the green. From Rand's vantage on the second floor, the neat lines of small, peaked tents reminded him of squares on a stones board. The soldiers had noticed the wind. Some pointed, others kept their heads down, polishing armor, carrying buckets of water to the horselines, sharpening swords or lance points. At least it was not the dead walking again. The most firm-hearted of men could lose their will when spirits rose from their graves, and Rand needed his army to be strong.

nid. noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɑz ɪɾ əbaʊt wʌt ɹænd wɑntəɾ əɹ wʌɾ i wɪʃt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ i dɪd foʊkəst oʊnli ɑn nid, ən wʌɾ i niɾəd moʊst wɑz ðə laɪvz ə ðoʊz u fɑloʊd hɪm. soʊlʒɝz tə faɪt, ən tə daɪ, tə pɹipɛɹ ðə wɝl fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. tɑɹmən ɡdən wɑz kʌmɪŋ. wʌɾ i niɾəd wɑz fəɹ əm ɔl tə bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə wɪn.

Need. No longer was it about what Rand wanted or what he wished. Everything he did focused only on need, and what he needed most was the lives of those who followed him. Soldiers to fight, and to die, to prepare the world for the Last Battle. Tarmon Gai'don was coming. What he needed was for them all to be strong enough to win.

tə ðə fɑɹ lɛft ə ðə ɡɹin, ɹʌnɪŋ bɪloʊ ðə mɑɾəst hɪl wɛɹ ðə mænɝ ɹɛstəd, ə twɪstɪŋ stʃɹim kʌt ðə ɡɹaʊnd, spɹaʊɾɪŋ wɪð jɛloʊ stɪkfɪŋɝ ɹidz ən skɹʌb oʊk ðət hæd jɛt tə sɛn aʊt spɹɪŋ bʌdz. ə smɔl wɔɾɝweɪ, tə bi sɝɾən, bʌɾ ə faɪn sɔɹs ə fɹɛʃ wɔɾɝ fəɹ ði ɑɹmi.

To the far left of the green, running below the modest hill where the manor rested, a twisting stream cut the ground, sprouting with yellow stickfinger reeds and scrub oak that had yet to send out spring buds. A small waterway, to be certain, but a fine source of fresh water for the army.

dʒʌst aʊtsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊ, ðə wɪnz sʌɾənli ɹaɪɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ðə flæɡz wɪpt ɝaʊnd, bloʊɪŋ ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən. soʊ ɪt hædn bɪn ðə niɾəlz æftɝ ɔl, bʌt ðə bænɝz ðət hæd bɪn ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ. mɪn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə sɑf saɪ, ən i kəd fil əɹ ɹɪlif, ðoʊ ʃi stɪl wɝiɾ əbaʊt hɪm.

Just outside the window, the winds suddenly righted themselves, and the flags whipped around, blowing in the other direction. So it hadn't been the needles after all, but the banners that had been in the wrong. Min let out a soft sigh, and he could feel her relief, though she still worried about him.

ðəɾ ɪmoʊʃən wɑz pɝpɛtʃuəl, leɪtli. hi fɛlt ɪt fɹəm ɔl ə ðɛm, itʃ ə ðə fɔɹ bʌndəlz ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz tʌkt əweɪ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. θɹi fəɹ ðə wɪmən i hæɾ əlaʊd tə pleɪs ðɛmsɛlvz ðɛɹ, wʌn fəɹ ðə wʊmən u hæd fɔɹst əɹ weɪ ɪn əɡɛnst ɪz wɪl. wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz dʒɹɔɪŋ kloʊsɝ.

That emotion was perpetual, lately. He felt it from all of them, each of the four bundles of emotions tucked away in the back of his mind. Three for the women he had allowed to place themselves there, one for the woman who had forced her way in against his will. One of them was drawing closer.

eɪvinhə, kʌmɪŋ wɪð ɹəɑɹk tə mit wɪð ɹænd ət ðə mænɝ haʊs.

Aviendha, coming with Rhuarc to meet with Rand at the manor house.

itʃ ə ðə fɔɹ wɪmən wəd ɹəɡɹɛt ðɛɹ dɪsɪʒən tə bɑn hɪm. hi wɪʃt i kəd ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən tə lɛɾ əm - ɔɹ, ət list, hɪz dɪsɪʒən tə əlaʊ ðə θɹi hi lʌvd. bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz ðəɾ i niɾəd mɪn, niɾəd əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ən əɹ lʌv. hi wəd juz əɹ əz i juz soʊ mɛni ʌðɝz. noʊ, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pleɪs ɪn ɪm fəɹ ɹəɡɹɛt. hi dʒʌst wɪʃt i kəd bænɪʃ ɡɪlt əz izəli.

Each of the four women would regret their decision to bond him. He wished he could regret his decision to let them - or, at least, his decision to allow the three he loved. But the truth was that he needed Min, needed her strength and her love. He would use her as he used so many others. No, there was no place in him for regret. He just wished he could banish guilt as easily.

aɪlaɪɛnə! ə vɔɪs sɛd dɪstənli ɪn ɹændz hɛd. maɪ lʌv. . . . luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, kɪnsleɪɝ, wɑz ɹɛləɾɪvli kwaɪət ðɪs deɪ. ɹænd tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk tu hɑɹɾ əbaʊt ðə θɪŋz sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd sɛɾ ɑn ðə deɪ wən ɹænd hæd lɔst ɪz hænd. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən; ʃi wəd seɪ ɛniθɪŋ ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wəd bɹɪŋ əɹ tɑɹɡət peɪn.

Ilyena! a voice said distantly in Rand's head. My love. . . . Lews Therin Telamon, Kinslayer, was relatively quiet this day. Rand tried not to think too hard about the things Semirhage had said on the day when Rand had lost his hand. She was one of the Forsaken; she would say anything if she thought it would bring her target pain.

ʃi tɔɹtʃɝɾ ən ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi tə pɹuv hɝsɛlf, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. ʃiz kɪld ə θaʊzən mɛn ə θaʊzən dɪfɹənt weɪz tə si haʊ ðɛɹ skɹimz wəd dɪfɝ fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝ. bʌt ʃi ɹɛɹli laɪz. ɹɛɹli.

She tortured an entire city to prove herself, Lews Therin whispered. She has killed a thousand men a thousand different ways to see how their screams would differ from one another. But she rarely lies. Rarely.

ɹænd pʊʃt ðə vɔɪs əweɪ.

Rand pushed the voice away.

"ɹænd," mɪn sɛd, sɑftɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ.

"Rand," Min said, softer than before.

hi tɝn tə lʊk ət hɝ. ʃi wɑz laɪð ən slaɪɾ ə bɪld, ən i ɔfən fɛl ðəɾ i taʊɝɾ oʊvɝ hɝ. ʃi kɛpt əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ʃɔɹt ɹɪŋləts, ðə kʌlɝ dɑɹk - bʌt nɑɾ əz dɑɹk əz əɹ dip, wɝiɾ aɪz. əz ɔlweɪz, ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən tə wɛɹ ə koʊɾ ən tʃɹaʊzɝz. tədeɪ, ðeɪ wɝ ʌv ə dip ɡɹin, mʌtʃ laɪk ðə niɾəlz ɑn ðə paɪnz aʊtsaɪd. jɛt, əz ɪf tə kɑntʃɹədɪkt əɹ teɪlɝd tʃɔɪs, ʃi hæd hæd ði aʊtfɪt meɪd tə əksɛntʃueɪɾ əɹ fɪɡjɝ. sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə boʊnəbɛl flaʊɝz ɹæn ɝaʊn ðə kʌfs, ən leɪs pikt aʊt fɹəm ðə slivz bɪniθ. ʃi smɛl feɪnli ʌv lævəndɝ, pɝhæps fɹəm ðə soʊp ʃid teɪkən tə moʊst ɹisənli.

He turned to look at her. She was lithe and slight of build, and he often felt that he towered over her. She kept her hair in short ringlets, the color dark - but not as dark as her deep, worried eyes. As always, she had chosen to wear a coat and trousers. Today, they were of a deep green, much like the needles on the pines outside. Yet, as if to contradict her tailored choice, she had had the outfit made to accentuate her figure. Silver embroidery in the shape of bonabell flowers ran around the cuffs, and lace peeked out from the sleeves beneath. She smelled faintly of lavender, perhaps from the soap she'd taken to most recently.

waɪ wɛɹ tʃɹaʊzɝz oʊnli tə tʃɹɪm hɝsɛlf ʌp wɪð leɪs? ɹænd hæd lɔŋ əbændən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʌndɝstænd wɪmən. ʌndɝstændɪŋ əm wəd nɑt hɛlp ɪm ɹitʃ ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. bɪsaɪdz, hi dɪdnt nid tə ʌndɝstænd wɪmən ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə juz ðɛm. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən i niɾəd.

Why wear trousers only to trim herself up with lace? Rand had long abandoned trying to understand women. Understanding them would not help him reach Shayol Ghul. Besides, he didn't need to understand women in order to use them. Particularly if they had information he needed.

hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. noʊ, hi θɔt. noʊ, ðəɹ ɑɹ laɪnz əl nɑt kɹɔs. ðəɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz ivən əl nɑt du.

He gritted his teeth. No, he thought. No, there are lines I will not cross. There are things even I will not do.

"jɔɹ θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ əɡɛn," mɪn sɛd, ɔlmoʊst əkjuzətɔɹi.

"You're thinking about her again," Min said, almost accusatory.

hi ɔfən wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz sətʃ ə θɪŋ əz ə bɑn ðət wɝkt oʊnli wʌn weɪ. hi wʊɾə ɡɪvən mʌtʃ fəɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz.

He often wondered if there was such a thing as a bond that worked only one way. He would have given much for one of those.

"ɹænd, ʃiz wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən," mɪn kəntɪnjud. "ʃi wʊɾə kɪld ɔl ʌv əs wɪθaʊɾ ə sɛkən θɔt."

"Rand, she's one of the Forsaken," Min continued. "She would have killed all of us without a second thought."

"ʃi wɑzn ɪntɛndɪŋ tə kɪl mi," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm mɪn ən lʊkɪŋ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ əɡɛn. "mi ʃi wəɾ əv hɛld."

"She wasn't intending to kill me," Rand said softly, turning away from Min and looking out the window again. "Me she would have held."

mɪn kɹɪnʒd. peɪn, wɝi. ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə twɪstəd meɪl æɾəm ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd bɹɔt, hɪɾən, wən ʃid kʌm ɪmpɝsəneɪɾɪŋ ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. ðə fɔɹseɪkənz dɪsɡaɪz hæd bɪn dɪsɹʌptɪd baɪ kædzueɪnz tɛɹæŋɡɹil, əlaʊɪŋ ɹænd tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz sɛmɝhɪdʒ. ɔɹəɡən, ət list, əlaʊɪŋ luz θɝɪn tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɝ.

Min cringed. Pain, worry. She was thinking of the twisted male a'dam that Semirhage had brought, hidden, when she'd come impersonating the Daughter of the Nine Moons. The Forsaken's disguise had been disrupted by Cadsuane's ter'angreal, allowing Rand to recognize Semirhage. Or, at least, allowing Lews Therin to recognize her.

ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ hæɾ ɛndəd wɪð ɹænd luzɪŋ ə hæn bʌt ɡeɪnɪŋ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən əz ɪz pɹɪznɝ.

The exchange had ended with Rand losing a hand but gaining one of the Forsaken as his prisoner.

ðə læs taɪm hid bɪn ɪn ə sɪməlɝ sɪtʃueɪʃən, ɪt hædn ɛndəd wɛl. hi stɪl dɪdnt noʊ wɛɹ æzmɑɾiən hæd ɡɔn əɹ waɪ ðə wizəl ʌv ə mæn hæd flɛɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, bʌt ɹænd dɪd səspɛk ðəɾ i hæd bɪtʃɹeɪd mʌtʃ əbaʊt ɹændz plænz ən æktɪvəɾiz.

The last time he'd been in a similar situation, it hadn't ended well. He still didn't know where Asmodean had gone or why the weasel of a man had fled in the first place, but Rand did suspect that he had betrayed much about Rand's plans and activities.

ʃʊɾə kɪl hɪm. ʃʊɾə kɪld əm ɔl.

Should have killed him. Should have killed them all.

ɹænd nɑɾəd, ðən fɹoʊz. hæd ðət bɪn luz θɝɪnz θɔɾ əɹ ɪz oʊn? luz θɝɪn, ɹænd θɔt. ɑɹ jə ðɛɹ?

Rand nodded, then froze. Had that been Lews Therin's thought or his own? Lews Therin, Rand thought. Are you there?

hi θɔɾ i hɝd læftɝ. əɹ pɝhæps ɪt wɑz sɑbɪŋ.

He thought he heard laughter. Or perhaps it was sobbing.

bɝn ju! ɹænd θɔt. tɔk tə mi! ðə taɪm ɪz kʌmɪŋ. aɪ nid tə noʊ wʌt jə noʊ! haʊ dɪd jə sil ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən? wʌt wɛn ɹɔŋ, ən waɪ dɪɾ ɪt liv ðə pɹɪzən flɔd?

Burn you! Rand thought. Talk to me! The time is coming. I need to know what you know! How did you seal the Dark One's prison? What went wrong, and why did it leave the prison flawed?

spik tə mi!

Speak to me!

jɛs, ðət wɑz dɛfənətli sɑbɪŋ, nɑt læftɝ. səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə tɛl wɪð luz θɝɪn.

Yes, that was definitely sobbing, not laughter. Sometimes it was hard to tell with Lews Therin.

ɹænd kəntɪnjud tə θɪŋk ə ðə dɛd mæn əz ə sɛpɹəɾ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl fɹəm hɪmsɛlf, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ʌv wʌt sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd sɛd. hi hæd klɛnz seɪɾɪn! ðə teɪnt wɑz ɡɔn ən ɪt kəd tʌtʃ ɪz maɪnd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə ɡoʊ ɪnseɪn.

Rand continued to think of the dead man as a separate individual from himself, regardless of what Semirhage had said. He had cleansed saidin! The taint was gone and it could touch his mind no longer. He was not going to go insane.

ðə dɪsɛn ɪndə tɝmənəl mædnəs kən bi . . . əbɹʌpt. hi hɝɾ əɹ wɝdz əɡɛn, spoʊkən fəɹ ði ʌðɝz tə hɪɹ. hɪz sikɹət wɑz faɪnəli aʊt. bʌt mɪn hæd sin ə vjuɪŋ ə ɹænd ən ənʌðɝ mæn mɛldəd təɡɛðɝ. dɪdn ðət min ðəɾ i ən luz θɝɪn wɝ tu sɛpɹət pipəl, tu ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz fɔɹst ɪndə wʌn bɑɾi?

The descent into terminal madness can be . . . abrupt. He heard her words again, spoken for the others to hear. His secret was finally out. But Min had seen a viewing of Rand and another man melded together. Didn't that mean that he and Lews Therin were two separate people, two individuals forced into one body?

ɪt meɪks noʊ dɪfɝəns ðəɾ ɪz vɔɪs ɪz ɹil, sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd sɛd. ɪn fækt, ɪt meɪks ɪz sɪtʃueɪʃən wɝs. . . .

It makes no difference that his voice is real, Semirhage had said. In fact, it makes his situation worse. . . .

ɹænd wɑtʃt ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɡɹup ə sɪks soʊlʒɝz ɪnspɛk ðə hɔɹslaɪnz ðət ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə ɹaɪt saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹin, bɪtwin ðə læs laɪn ə tɛns ən ðə laɪn ə tʃɹiz. ðeɪ tʃɛk ðə hʊvz wʌn əɾ ə taɪm.

Rand watched a particular group of six soldiers inspect the horselines that ran along the right side of the green, between the last line of tents and the line of trees. They checked the hooves one at a time.

ɹænd kʊdn θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪz mædnəs. hi ɔlsoʊ kʊdn θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt kædzueɪn wɑz duɪŋ wɪð sɛmɝhɪdʒ. ðət lɛft oʊnli hɪz plænz. ðə nɔɹθ ən ði is mʌs bi əz wʌn. ðə wɛst ən ðə saʊθ mʌs bi əz wʌn. ðə tu mʌs bi əz wʌn. ðət wɑz ði ænsɝ hid ɹəsiv fɹəm ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹitʃɝz bɪɑn ðə ɹɛd stoʊn dɔɹweɪ. ɪt wɑz ɔl i hæd tə ɡoʊ ɑn.

Rand couldn't think about his madness. He also couldn't think about what Cadsuane was doing with Semirhage. That left only his plans. The north and the east must be as one. The west and the south must be as one. The two must be as one. That was the answer he'd received from the strange creatures beyond the red stone doorway. It was all he had to go on.

nɔɹθ ən ist. hi hæd tə fɔɹs ðə lænz ɪndə pis, wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ɪɾ əɹ nɑt. hi hæɾ ə tɛnjəwəs bæləns ɪn ði ist, wɪð ɪljən, min, kɛɹhin ən tɛɹ ɔl ʌndɝ ɪz kəntʃɹoʊl ɪn wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. ðə sintʃæn ɹuld ɪn ðə saʊθ, wɪð ɔltɑɹə, ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən tæɹɑbən ʌndɝ ðɛɹ kəntʃɹoʊl.

North and east. He had to force the lands into peace, whether they wanted it or not. He had a tenuous balance in the east, with Illian, Mayene, Cairhien and Tear all under his control in one way or another. The Seanchan ruled in the south, with Altara, Amadicia and Tarabon under their control.

mʊɹændi maɪt sun bi ðɛɹz, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ pɹɛsɪŋ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən. ðət lɛft ændɝ ən ɪleɪn.

Murandy might soon be theirs, if they were pressing in that direction. That left Andor and Elayne.

ɪleɪn. ʃi wɑz dɪstənt, fɑɹ tə ði ist, bʌɾ i kəd stɪl fil əɹ bʌndəl ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn ɪz hɛd.

Elayne. She was distant, far to the east, but he could still feel her bundle of emotions in his head.

ət sətʃ ə dɪstəns, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl mʌtʃ, bʌɾ i θɔt ʃi wɑz . . . ɹɪlivd. dɪd ðət min ðəɾ əɹ stʃɹʌɡəl fəɹ paʊɝ ɪn ændɝ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ wɛl? wʌɾ ə ði ɑɹmiz ðət hæd bɪsidʒ hɝ? ən wʌt wɝ ðoʊz bɔɹɾɝləndɝz ʌp tə? ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðɛɹ poʊsts, dʒɔɪnɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ən mɑɹtʃɪŋ saʊθ tə faɪn ɹænd, bʌt ɡɪvɪŋ noʊ ɛkspləneɪʃən ʌv wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ə hɪm. ðeɪ wɝ səm ə ðə bɛst soʊlʒɝz wɛst ə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. ðɛɹ hɛlp wəd bi ɪnvæljəbəl ət ðə læs bæɾəl. bʌt ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðə nɔɹθlənz. waɪ?

At such a distance, it was difficult to tell much, but he thought she was . . . relieved. Did that mean that her struggle for power in Andor was going well? What of the armies that had besieged her? And what were those Borderlanders up to? They had left their posts, joining together and marching south to find Rand, but giving no explanation of what they wanted of him. They were some of the best soldiers west of the Spine of the World. Their help would be invaluable at the Last Battle. But they had left the northlands. Why?

hi wɑz loʊθ tə kənfɹʌn ðɛm, haʊɛvɝ, fəɹ fɪɹ ɪt kəd min jɛɾ ənʌðɝ faɪt. wʌn i kʊdn əfɔɹɾ ət ðə moʊmənt. laɪt! hi wʊɾə θɔt ðæt, ʌv ɔl pipəl, hi cʊɾə dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz tə səpɔɹɾ ɪm əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ.

He was loath to confront them, however, for fear it could mean yet another fight. One he couldn't afford at the moment. Light! He would have thought that, of all people, he could have depended on the Borderlanders to support him against the Shadow.

noʊ mæɾɝ, nɑt fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. hi hæd pis, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ kloʊs tə ɪt, ɪn moʊst ə ðə lænd. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə ɹisənli plækeɪɾɪd ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛnst ɪm ɪn tiɹ əɹ ðə vɑlətɪləɾi ʌv ðə bɔɹɾɝz wɪð sintʃæn lænz, əɹ ðə plɑɾɪŋz ə ðə noʊbɪləɾi ɪn kɛɹhin. ɛvɹi taɪm i θɔɾ i hæɾ ə neɪʃən sɪkjʊɹ, ɪt simd ə dʌzən ʌðɝz fɛl əpɑɹt. haʊ kəɾ i bɹɪŋ pis tə ə pipəl u ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɪt?

No matter, not for the moment. He had peace, or something close to it, in most of the land. He tried not to think about the recently placated rebellion against him in Tear or the volatility of the borders with Seanchan lands, or the plottings of the nobility in Cairhien. Every time he thought he had a nation secure, it seemed a dozen others fell apart. How could he bring peace to a people who refused to accept it?

mɪnz fɪŋɡɝz taɪɾənd ɑn ɪz ɑɹm, ən i tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. hi dɪd wʌɾ i kʊd, ən fəɹ naʊ, hi hæd tu ɡoʊlz. pis ɪn ɑɹæd dumən ən ə tʃɹus wɪð ðə sintʃæn. ðə wɝdz hid ɹəsiv bɪɑn ðə dɔɹweɪ wɝ naʊ klɪɹ: hi kəd nɑt faɪt boʊθ ðə sintʃæn ən ðə dɑɹk wʌn. hi hæd tə kip ðə sintʃæn fɹəm ədvænsɪŋ əntɪl ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz oʊvɝ. æftɝ ðæt, ðə laɪt kəd bɝn əm ɔl.

Min's fingers tightened on his arm, and he took a deep breath. He did what he could, and for now, he had two goals. Peace in Arad Doman and a truce with the Seanchan. The words he'd received beyond the doorway were now clear: He could not fight both the Seanchan and the Dark One. He had to keep the Seanchan from advancing until the Last Battle was over. After that, the Light could burn them all.

waɪ hæd ðə sintʃæn ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪz ɹɪkwɛsts fəɹ ə miɾɪŋ? wɝ ðeɪ æŋɡɝd ðəɾ i hæd kæptʃɝd sɛmɝhɪdʒ? hi hæd lɛt ðə sʌldəm ɡoʊ fɹi. dɪd ðət nɑt spik ə hɪz ɡʊd feɪθ? ɑɹæd dumən wəd pɹuv ɪz ɪntɛntʃənz. ɪf i kəɾ ɛn ðə faɪɾ ɪn ɑlməθ pleɪn, hi kəd ʃoʊ ðə sintʃæn ðəɾ i wɑz sɪɹiəs ɪn ɪz suts fəɹ pis. hi wəd meɪk əm si!

Why had the Seanchan ignored his requests for a meeting? Were they angered that he had captured Semirhage? He had let the sul'dam go free. Did that not speak of his good faith? Arad Doman would prove his intentions. If he could end the fight in Almoth Plain, he could show the Seanchan that he was serious in his suits for peace. He would make them see!

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, stʌɾiɪŋ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ. bæʃɪɹz eɪt θaʊzən soʊlʒɝz wɝ ɪɹɛktɪŋ pik tɛns ən dɪɡɪŋ ən ɝθən moʊɾ ən wɔl ɝaʊn ðə ɡɹin. ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ bʊlwɝk ə dip bɹaʊn kəntʃɹæstəd wɪð ðə waɪt tɛns. ɹænd hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ði æʃəmən tə hɛlp wɪð ðə dɪɡɪŋ, ən ðoʊ hi daʊɾɪd ðeɪ ɛndʒɔɪd ðə hʌmbəl wɝk, ɪt dɪd spid ðə pɹɑsɛs ɡɹeɪtli. bɪsaɪdz, ɹænd səspɛktəd ðət ðeɪ - laɪk i hɪmsɛlf - sikɹɪtli seɪvɝɾ ɛni ɪkskjus tə hoʊl seɪɾɪn. hi kəd si ə smɔl ɡɹup ə ðɛm ɪn ðɛɹ stɪf blæk koʊts, wivz spɪnɪŋ ɝaʊn əm əz ðeɪ dʌɡ ʌp ənʌðɝ pætʃ ʌv ɡɹaʊnd. ðəɹ wɝ tɛn ə ðɛm ɪn ðə kæmp, ðoʊ oʊnli flɪn, nf ən nɛɹɪʃmə wɝ fʊl æʃəmən.

Rand took a deep breath, studying out the window. Bashere's eight thousand soldiers were erecting peaked tents and digging an earthen moat and wall around the green. The growing bulwark of deep brown contrasted with the white tents. Rand had ordered the Asha'man to help with the digging, and though he doubted they enjoyed the humble work, it did speed the process greatly. Besides, Rand suspected that they - like he himself - secretly savored any excuse to hold saidin. He could see a small group of them in their stiff black coats, weaves spinning around them as they dug up another patch of ground. There were ten of them in the camp, though only Flinn, Naeff and Narishma were full Asha'man.

ðə sɑldəiənz wɝkt kwɪkli, wɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃɔɹt koʊts əz ðeɪ kɛɹd fəɹ ðɛɹ maʊns ən sɛt pɪkəts. ʌðɝz tʊk ʃʌvɛlfəlz ə dɝt fɹəm ði æʃəmən maʊn ən juzd ɪt tə pæk ɪndə ðə bʊlwɝk.

The Saldaeans worked quickly, wearing their short coats as they cared for their mounts and set pickets. Others took shovelfuls of dirt from the Asha'man mound and used it to pack into the bulwark.

ɹænd kəd si ðəɹ wɑz ðət dɪsplɛʒɝ ɑn ðə feɪsəz ə mɛni ʌv ðə hɔk-noʊz sɑldəiənz. ðeɪ dɪdn laɪk meɪkɪŋ kæmp ɪn ə wʊɾɪd ɛɹiə, ivən wʌn əz spɑɹsli flɛkt wɪð paɪn əz ðɪs hɪlsaɪd.

Rand could see there was that displeasure on the faces of many of the hawk-nosed Saldaeans. They didn't like making camp in a wooded area, even one as sparsely flecked with pine as this hillside.

tʃɹiz meɪd kævəlɹi tʃɑɹdʒəz dɪfəkəlt ən kəd haɪɾ ɛnəmiz əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt.

Trees made cavalry charges difficult and could hide enemies as they approached.

dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ hɪmsɛlf ɹoʊd sloʊli θɹu ðə kæmp, bɑɹkɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz θɹu ðət θɪk mʌstæʃ ə hɪz. bɪsaɪɾ ɪm wɔk lɔɹd tɛleɪən, ə pɔɹtli mæn ɪn ə lɔŋ koʊɾ ən wɛɹɪŋ ə θɪn dəmɑni mʌstæʃ. hi wɑz ən əkweɪntəns ə bæʃɪɹz.

Davram Bashere himself rode slowly through the camp, barking orders through that thick mustache of his. Beside him walked Lord Tellaen, a portly man in a long coat and wearing a thin Domani mustache. He was an acquaintance of Bashere's.

lɔɹd tɛleɪən pʊt hɪmsɛlf ət ɹɪsk baɪ haʊzɪŋ ɹænd; ʃɛltɝɪŋ ðə tʃɹups ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kəd bi sin əz tʃɹizən. bʌɾ u wɑz ðəɹ tə pʌnɪʃ hɪm? ɑɹæd dumən wɑz ɪn keɪɑs, ðə θɹoʊn ʌndɝ θɹɛt fɹəm sɛvɹəl ɹɛbəl fækʃənz. ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz ðə ɡɹeɪt dəmɑni dʒɛnɝəl ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi ən ɪz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli ɪfɛktɪv wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn tə ðə saʊθ.

Lord Tellaen put himself at risk by housing Rand; sheltering the troops of the Dragon Reborn could be seen as treason. But who was there to punish him? Arad Doman was in chaos, the throne under threat from several rebel factions. And then there was the great Domani general Rodel Ituralde and his surprisingly effective war against the Seanchan to the south.

laɪk ɪz mɛn, bæʃɪɹ wɛn əbaʊɾ ənɑɹmɝɾ ɪn ə ʃɔɹt blu koʊt. hi ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ə pɛɹ ə ðə bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz ðəɾ i feɪvɝd, ðə bɑɾəmz tʌkt ɪndə hɪz ni-haɪ buts. wʌd bæʃɪɹ θɪŋk ə biɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn ɹændz tɑvɝən wɛb? ɪn biɪŋ, ɪf nɑɾ ɪn dɝɛkt ɑpəzɪʃən tə ðə wɪl ə hɪz kwin, ət list ənkʌmftəbli tə ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɪt? haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ ɪt bɪn sɪns i hæd ɹipɔɹɾəd tə hɪz ɹaɪtfəl ɹulɝ?

Like his men, Bashere went about unarmored in a short blue coat. He also wore a pair of the baggy trousers that he favored, the bottoms tucked into his knee-high boots. What did Bashere think of being caught in Rand's ta'veren web? In being, if not in direct opposition to the will of his queen, at least uncomfortably to the side of it? How long had it been since he had reported to his rightful ruler?

hædn i pɹɑməst ɹænd ðəɾ ɪz kwinz səpɔɹt wəd bi spiɾi ɪn kʌmɪŋ? haʊ mɛni mʌnθs əɡoʊ hæd ðət bɪn?

Hadn't he promised Rand that his queen's support would be speedy in coming? How many months ago had that been?

aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ɹænd θɔt. aɪ bɹeɪk ɔl kʌvənəns ən vaʊz. oʊld ælidʒiænsɪz ɑɹ ənɪmpɔɹɾənt. oʊnli tɑɹmən ɡdən mæɾɝz. tɑɹmən ɡdən, ən ðə sɝvəns ə ðə ʃædoʊ.

I am the Dragon Reborn, Rand thought. I break all covenants and vows. Old allegiances are unimportant. Only Tarmon Gai'don matters. Tarmon Gai'don, and the servants of the Shadow.

"aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf wɪl faɪnd ɡɹeɪndəl hɪɹ," ɹænd sɛd θɔtfəli.

"I wonder if we'll find Graendal here," Rand said thoughtfully.

"ɡɹeɪndəl?" mɪn æskt. "wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk ʃi maɪt bi?"

"Graendal?" Min asked. "What makes you think she might be?"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. æzmɑɾiən hæd sɛd ɡɹeɪndəl wɑz ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, ðoʊ ðət hæd bɪn mʌnθs əɡoʊ. wɑz ʃi stɪl hɪɹ? ɪt sim plɔzəbəl; ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju meɪdʒɝ neɪʃənz wɛɹ ʃi kəd bi. ɡɹeɪndəl laɪk tə hæv ə hɪɾən beɪs ə paʊɝ fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən lɝkt;

Rand shook his head. Asmodean had said Graendal was in Arad Doman, though that had been months ago. Was she still here? It seemed plausible; it was one of the few major nations where she could be. Graendal liked to have a hidden base of power far from where the other Forsaken lurked;

ʃi wʊdn əv sɛɾ ʌp ɪn ændɝ, tiɹ əɹ ɪljən. nɔɹ wəd ʃi hæv bɪn kɑɾ ɪn ðə lænz tə ðə saʊθwɛst, nɑt wɪð ðə sintʃæn ɪnveɪʒən.

she wouldn't have set up in Andor, Tear or Illian. Nor would she have been caught in the lands to the southwest, not with the Seanchan invasion.

ʃi wəɾ əv ə hɪɾən ɹitʃɹit sʌmwɛɹ. ðət wɑz haʊ ʃi ɑpɝeɪɾəd. pɹɑbli ɪn ðə maʊntənz, sɪkluɾɪd, sʌmwɛɹ hɪɹ ɪn ðə nɔɹθ. hi kʊdn bi ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, ðoʊ ɪt fɛlt ɹaɪt tə hɪm, fɹəm wʌɾ i nu ʌv hɝ. fɹəm wʌt luz θɝɪn nu ʌv hɝ.

She would have a hidden retreat somewhere. That was how she operated. Probably in the mountains, secluded, somewhere here in the north. He couldn't be sure she was in Arad Doman, though it felt right to him, from what he knew of her. From what Lews Therin knew of her.

bʌɾ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə pɑsəbɪləɾi. hi wəd bi kɛɹfəl, wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ hɝ. itʃ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ðəɾ i ɹimuvd wəd meɪk ðə læs bæɾəl ðət mʌtʃ iziɝ tə faɪt. ɪt wəd -  sɑft fʊtstɛps əpɹoʊtʃt ɪz kloʊz dɔɹ.

But it was only a possibility. He would be careful, watching for her. Each of the Forsaken that he removed would make the Last Battle that much easier to fight. It would -  Soft footsteps approached his closed door.

ɹænd ɹilis mɪn ən ðeɪ boʊθ spʌn, ɹænd ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd - ə jusləs dʒɛstʃɝ, naʊ. ðə lɔs ə hɪz hænd, ðoʊ ɪt wɑzn ɪz pɹaɪmɛɹi sɔɹd hænd, wəd liv ɪm vʌlnɝəbəl ɪf i wɝ tə feɪs ə skɪld əpoʊnənt. ivən wɪð seɪɾɪn tə pɹəvaɪɾ ə fɑɹ mɔɹ poʊɾənt wɛpən, hɪz fɝst ɪnstɪŋkt wɑz fəɹ ðə sɔɹd. hiɾ əv tə tʃeɪnʒ ðæt. ɪt maɪt ɡɛɾ ɪm kɪl sʌmdeɪ.

Rand released Min and they both spun, Rand reaching for his sword - a useless gesture, now. The loss of his hand, though it wasn't his primary sword hand, would leave him vulnerable if he were to face a skilled opponent. Even with saidin to provide a far more potent weapon, his first instinct was for the sword. He'd have to change that. It might get him killed someday.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ən kædzueɪn stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn, əz kɑnfəɾənt əz ɛni kwin ət kɔɹt. ʃi wɑz ə hænsəm wʊmən, wɪð dɑɹk aɪz ən ən æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs. hɝ dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ wɑz ʌp ɪn ə bʌn, ə dʌzən taɪni ɡoʊldən ɔɹnəməns - itʃ wʌn ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil əɹ æŋɡɹil - hæŋɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪsəz ətɑp ɪt. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz ʌv ə sɪmpəl, θɪk wʊl, taɪɾ ət ðə weɪst wɪð ə jɛloʊ bɛlt, wɪð mɔɹ jɛloʊ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi əkɹɔs ðə kɑlɝ. ðə dʒɹɛs ɪtsɛlf wɑz ɡɹin, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑɾ ənkɑmən, əz ðət wɑz əɹ ədʒɑ. ɹænd səmtaɪmz fɛl ðəɾ əɹ stɝn feɪs - eɪdʒləs, laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd wɝk lɔŋ ɪnʌf wɪð ðə paʊɝ - wʊɾə fɪt bɛɾɝ ɪn ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ.

The door opened and Cadsuane strode in, as confident as any queen at court. She was a handsome woman, with dark eyes and an angular face. Her dark gray hair was up in a bun, a dozen tiny golden ornaments - each one a ter'angreal or angreal - hanging in their places atop it. Her dress was of a simple, thick wool, tied at the waist with a yellow belt, with more yellow embroidery across the collar. The dress itself was green, which was not uncommon, as that was her Ajah. Rand sometimes felt that her stern face - ageless, like that of any Aes Sedai who had worked long enough with the Power - would have fit better in the Red Ajah.

hi ɹɪlækst ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd, ðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt ɹilis ɪt. hi fɪŋɡɝd ðə klɔθ-taɪd hɪlt. ðə wɛpən wɑz lɔŋ, slaɪtli kɝvd, ən ðə lækɝd skæbɝd wɑz peɪntəd wɪð ə lɔŋ, sɪnwəs dʒɹæɡən ə ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld. ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn dɪzaɪn spəsɪfɪkli fəɹ ɹænd - ən jɛɾ ɪt wɑz sɛntʃɝiz oʊld, ənɝθt oʊnli ɹisənli. haʊ ɑd, ðət ðeɪ ʃəd faɪn ðɪs naʊ, hi θɔt, ən meɪk ə ɡɪft ʌv ɪt tə mi, kəmplitli ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv wʌt ðeɪ wɝ hoʊldɪŋ. . . .

He relaxed his hand on his sword, though he did not release it. He fingered the cloth-tied hilt. The weapon was long, slightly curved, and the lacquered scabbard was painted with a long, sinuous dragon of red and gold. It looked as if it had been designed specifically for Rand - and yet it was centuries old, unearthed only recently. How odd, that they should find this now, he thought, and make a gift of it to me, completely unaware of what they were holding. . . .

hi hæd teɪkən tə wɛɹɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ ɪmiɾiətli. ɪt fɛlt ɹaɪt bɪniθ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. hi hæd toʊl noʊ wʌn, nɑɾ ivən mɪn, ðəɾ i hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə wɛpən. ən nɑt, ɑdli, fɹəm luz θɝɪnz mɛmɹiz  - bʌt ɹændz oʊn.

He had taken to wearing the sword immediately. It felt right beneath his fingers. He had told no one, not even Min, that he had recognized the weapon. And not, oddly, from Lews Therin's memories  - but Rand's own.

kædzueɪn wɑz əkʌmpənid baɪ sɛvɹəl ʌðɝz. nɪneɪiv wɑz ɪkspɛktəd; ʃi ɔfən fɑloʊd kædzueɪn ðiz deɪz, laɪk ə ɹaɪvəl kæt ʃi faʊn ɪnkɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɑn əɹ tɛɹɪtɔɹi. ʃi dɪɾ ɪt fəɹ hɪm, laɪkli.

Cadsuane was accompanied by several others. Nynaeve was expected; she often followed Cadsuane these days, like a rival cat she found encroaching on her territory. She did it for him, likely.

ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɛvɝ kwaɪt ɡɪvən ʌp biɪŋ wɪzdəm ʌv ɛmənz fild, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ʃi sɛd, ən ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ kɔɹɾɝ tə ɛniwʌn ʃi θɔt wɑz əbjuzɪŋ wʌn ʌndɝ əɹ pɹətɛkʃən. ənlɛs, ʌv kɔɹs, nɪneɪiv hɝsɛlf wɑz ðə wʌn duɪŋ ði əbjuzɪŋ.

The dark-haired Aes Sedai had never quite given up being Wisdom of Emond's Field, no matter what she said, and she gave no quarter to anyone she thought was abusing one under her protection. Unless, of course, Nynaeve herself was the one doing the abusing.

tədeɪ, ʃi wɔɹ ə dʒɹɛs ʌv ɡɹeɪ wɪð ə jɛloʊ sæʃ ət ðə weɪst oʊvɝ əɹ bɛlt - ə nu dəmɑni fæʃən, hi hæd hɝd - ən hæd ðə kʌstəmɛɹi ɹɛd dɑɾ ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd. ʃi wɔɹ ə lɔŋ ɡoʊl nɛkləs ən slɪm ɡoʊl bɛlt, wɪð mætʃɪŋ bɹeɪslɪts ən fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋz, boʊθ stʌɾɪd wɪð lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd, ɡɹin ən blu dʒɛmz. ðə dʒuəlɹi wɑz ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil - ɔɹ, ɹæðɝ, sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm ən ən æŋɡɹil tu -  kɑmpɝəbəl tə wʌt kædzueɪn wɔɹ. ɹænd hæɾ əkeɪʒənəli hɝd nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝɪŋ ðəɾ əɹ tɛɹæŋɡɹil, wɪð ðə ɡɔɾi dʒɛmz, wɝ ɪmpɑsəbəl tə mætʃ tə hɝ kloʊðɪŋ.

Today, she wore a dress of gray with a yellow sash at the waist over her belt - a new Domani fashion, he had heard - and had the customary red dot on her forehead. She wore a long gold necklace and slim gold belt, with matching bracelets and finger rings, both studded with large red, green and blue gems. The jewelry was a ter'angreal - or, rather, several of them and an angreal too -  comparable to what Cadsuane wore. Rand had occasionally heard Nynaeve muttering that her ter'angreal, with the gaudy gems, were impossible to match to her clothing.

wɛɹ nɪneɪiv wɑzn ə sɝpɹaɪz, əliviə wɑz. ɹænd hædn bɪn əwɛɹ ðət ðə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn hæd bɪn ɪnvɑlvd ɪn ði . . . ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɡæðɝɪŋ. stɪl, ʃi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ivən stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən nɪneɪiv ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ, soʊ pɝhæps ʃi hæd bɪn bɹɔt fəɹ səpɔɹt. wʌn kəd nɛvɝ bi tu kɛɹfəl wɛɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɝ kənsɝnd.

Where Nynaeve wasn't a surprise, Alivia was. Rand hadn't been aware that the former damane had been involved in the . . . information gathering. Still, she was supposed to be even stronger than Nynaeve in the One Power, so perhaps she had been brought for support. One could never be too careful where the Forsaken were concerned.

ðəɹ wɝ stʃɹiks ʌv waɪɾ ɪn əliviəz hɛɹ, ən ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ə bɪt tɔlɝ ðən nɪneɪiv. ðət waɪɾ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ wɑz tɛlɪŋ - ɛni waɪɾ əɹ ɡɹeɪ ɑn ə wʊmən u wildɪd ðə wʌn paʊɝ mɛn eɪdʒ.

There were streaks of white in Alivia's hair, and she was just a bit taller than Nynaeve. That white in her hair was telling - any white or gray on a woman who wielded the One Power meant age.

ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɪt. əliviə kleɪm tə bi fɔɹ sɛntʃɝiz oʊld. tədeɪ, ðə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn wɔɹ ə stʃɹaɪkɪŋli ɹɛd dʒɹɛs, əz ɪf ɪn ən ətɛmp tə bi kɑnfɹənteɪʃənəl. moʊs deɪmeɪn, wʌns ənliʃt, ɹɪmeɪn tɪmɪd. nɑt soʊ wɪð əliviə - ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪntɛnsəɾi tə hɝ ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst sədʒɛstəɾ ə waɪtkloʊk.

A great deal of it. Alivia claimed to be four centuries old. Today, the former damane wore a strikingly red dress, as if in an attempt to be confrontational. Most damane, once unleashed, remained timid. Not so with Alivia - there was an intensity to her that almost suggested a Whitecloak.

hi fɛl mɪn stɪfən, ən i fɛlt əɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ. əliviə wəd hɛlp ɹænd daɪ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ðət hæd bɪn wʌn ə mɪnz vjuɪŋz - ən mɪnz vjuɪŋz wɝ nɛvɝ ɹɔŋ. ɪksɛp ðət ʃid sɛd ʃid bɪn ɹɔŋ əbaʊt mɔɪɹeɪn. pɝhæps ðət mɛn ðəɾ i wʊdn əv tə . . .

He felt Min stiffen, and he felt her displeasure. Alivia would help Rand die, eventually. That had been one of Min's viewings - and Min's viewings were never wrong. Except that she'd said she'd been wrong about Moiraine. Perhaps that meant that he wouldn't have to . . .

noʊ. ɛniθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə lɪvɪŋ θɹu ðə læs bæɾəl, ɛniθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm hoʊp, wɑz deɪnʒɝəs. hi hæd tə bi hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə æksɛpt wʌt wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə hɪm. hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə daɪ wən ðə taɪm keɪm.

No. Anything that made him think of living through the Last Battle, anything that made him hope, was dangerous. He had to be hard enough to accept what was coming to him. Hard enough to die when the time came.

jə sɛd wi kəd daɪ, luz θɝɪn sɛɾ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. jə pɹɑməst!

You said we could die, Lews Therin said in the back of his mind. You promised!

kædzueɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ əz ʃi wɔkt əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, hɛlpɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ə kʌp ə ðə spaɪst waɪn ðət sæɾ ɑn ə smɔl sɝvɪŋ teɪbəl bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd. ðən ʃi sæt daʊn ɪn wʌn ə ðə ɹɛd siɾɝ tʃɛɹz. ət list ʃi hædn dɪmændəd ðəɾ i pɔɹ ðə waɪn fəɹ hɝ. ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ wɑzn bɪɑn hɝ.

Cadsuane said nothing as she walked across the room, helping herself to a cup of the spiced wine that sat on a small serving table beside the bed. Then she sat down in one of the red cedar chairs. At least she hadn't demanded that he pour the wine for her. That sort of thing wasn't beyond her.

"wɛl, wʌd jə lɝn?" hi æskt, wɔkɪŋ fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ ən pɔɹɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ə kʌp ʌv waɪn əz wɛl. mɪn wɔk tə ðə bɛd - wɪð ɪts fɹeɪm ə siɾɝ lɔɡz ən ə skɪp-pil hɛdbɔɹd steɪn dipli ɹɛɾɪʃ bɹaʊn - ən sæt daʊn, hænz ɪn əɹ læp. ʃi wɑtʃt əliviə kɛɹfəli.

"Well, what did you learn?" he asked, walking from the window and pouring himself a cup of wine as well. Min walked to the bed - with its frame of cedar logs and a skip-peeled headboard stained deeply reddish brown - and sat down, hands in her lap. She watched Alivia carefully.

kædzueɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ðə ʃɑɹpnəs ɪn ɹændz vɔɪs. hi saɪd, fɔɹsɪŋ daʊn ɪz ənɔɪəns. hi hæɾ æskt əɹ tə bi hɪz kaʊnsəlɝ, ən i hæɾ əɡɹid tə hɝ stɪpjəleɪʃənz. mɪn sɛd ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt i wəd nid tə lɝn fɹəm kædzueɪn - ðət wɑz ənʌðɝ vjuɪŋ -  ən ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi hæd faʊn əɹ ædvaɪs jusfəl ɑn mɔɹ ðən wʌn əkeɪʒən. ʃi wɑz wɝθ əɹ kɑnstən dɪmænz fəɹ dɪkɔɹəm.

Cadsuane raised an eyebrow at the sharpness in Rand's voice. He sighed, forcing down his annoyance. He had asked her to be his counselor, and he had agreed to her stipulations. Min said there was something important he would need to learn from Cadsuane - that was another viewing -  and in truth, he had found her advice useful on more than one occasion. She was worth her constant demands for decorum.

"haʊ dɪd ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɡoʊ, kædzueɪn sədaɪ?" hi æskt ɪn ə mɔɹ mɑɾɝət toʊn.

"How did the questioning go, Cadsuane Sedai?" he asked in a more moderate tone.

ʃi smaɪl tə hɝsɛlf. "wɛl ɪnʌf."

She smiled to herself. "Well enough."

"wɛl ɪnʌf?" nɪneɪiv snæpt. ʃi hæd meɪd noʊ pɹɑməsəz tə kædzueɪn əbaʊt səvɪləɾi. "ðæt wʊmən ɪz ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ!"

"Well enough?" Nynaeve snapped. She had made no promises to Cadsuane about civility. "That woman is infuriating!"

ʃiz hæɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm tə pɹæktəs biɪŋ . . . ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ."

All she does is explain how inferior and backward we are, with the occasional aside that she's eventually going to kill us all." Nynaeve reached up to her long, single braid - but stopped herself short of tugging on it. She was getting better about that. Rand wondered why she bothered, considering how obvious her temper was.

"fɔɹ ɔl ðə ɡɝlz dʒɹəmæɾɪk tɔk," kædzueɪn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə nɪneɪiv, "ʃi hæz ə ɹizənəbəl ɡɹæsp ɑn ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən. fɔ! wən aɪ sɛd 'wɛl ɪnʌf' jə wɝ tə ɪntɝpɹəɾ ɪɾ əz 'æz wɛl əz jə maɪɾ ɪkspɛkt, ɡɪvən əɹ ənfɔɹtʃənət kənstʃɹeɪns.' wʌn kænɑt blaɪndfoʊld ən ɑɹɾəst, ðən bi sɝpɹaɪzd wən hiz nʌθɪŋ tə peɪnt."

"For all the girl's dramatic talk," Cadsuane said, nodding to Nynaeve, "she has a reasonable grasp on the situation. Phaw! When I said 'well enough' you were to interpret it as 'as well as you might expect, given our unfortunate constraints.' One cannot blindfold an artist, then be surprised when he has nothing to paint."

"This isn't art, Cadsuane," Rand said dryly. "It's torture." Min shared a glance with him, and he felt her concern. Concern for him? He wasn't the one being tortured.

ðə bɑks, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. wi ʃʊɾə daɪɾ ɪn ðə bɑks. ðən . . . ðən ɪt wəd bi oʊvɝ.

The box, Lews Therin whispered. We should have died in the box. Then . . . then it would be over.

"No!" Rand growled, waving a hand . . . a stump . . . at her. "You will not threaten or hurt her."

taɪm spɛn ɪn ə dɑɹk bɑks, biɪŋ pʊl fɔɹθ ən biɪŋ biɾən ɹɪpiɾɪdli. hi wəd nɑɾ əv ə wʊmən ɪn ɪz paʊɝ tʃɹiɾəd ðə seɪm weɪ. nɑɾ ivən wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. "ju meɪ kwɛstʃən hɝ, bʌt səm θɪŋz əl nɑɾ əlaʊ."

Time spent in a dark box, being pulled forth and being beaten repeatedly. He would not have a woman in his power treated the same way. Not even one of the Forsaken. "You may question her, but some things I will not allow."

nɪneɪiv snɪft. "ɹænd, ʃiz wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, deɪnʒɝəs bɪɑn ɹizən!"

Nynaeve sniffed. "Rand, she's one of the Forsaken, dangerous beyond reason!"

"I am aware of the threat," Rand said flatly, holding up the stump where his left hand had been.

ðə mətælɪk ɡoʊld ən ɹɛd tætu ʌv ə dʒɹæɡənz bɑɾi spɑɹkəld ɪn ðə læmplaɪt. ɪts hɛd hæd bɪn kənsumd ɪn ðə faɪɝ ðət hæd nɪɹli kɪl hɪm.

The metallic gold and red tattoo of a dragon's body sparkled in the lamplight. Its head had been consumed in the Fire that had nearly killed him.

nɪneɪiv tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "jɛs, wɛl, ðən jə mʌst si ðət nɔɹməl ɹulz ʃʊdn əplaɪ tə hɝ!"

"aɪ sɛd noʊ!" ɹænd sɛd. "ju wɪl kwɛstʃən hɝ, bʌt jəl nɑt hɝt hɝ!" nɑɾ ə wʊmən. əl kip tə ðɪs wʌn ʃɹɛɾ ə laɪɾ ɪnsaɪd mi. aɪv kɑz ðə dɛθs ən sɑɹoʊz ə tu mɛni wɪmən ɔlɹɛɾi.

"I said no!" Rand said. "You will question her, but you will not hurt her!" Not a woman. I will keep to this one shred of light inside me. I've caused the deaths and sorrows of too many women already.

pɝhæps wi ʃəd sɪmpli tɝn əɹ oʊvɝ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən bi dʌn wɪð ɪt."

Perhaps we should simply turn her over to the White Tower and be done with it."

ɹænd tɝn əweɪ. aʊtsaɪd, ðə soʊlʒɝz hæd fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðə hɔɹslaɪnz. ðeɪ lʊkt ɡʊd. ivən ən stʃɹeɪt, ði ænəməlz ɡɪvən dʒʌs ðə ɹaɪɾ əmaʊn ə slæk.

"wɪtʃ waɪt taʊɝ? wəd jə ɛntʃɹʌst əɹ tə ɪleɪɾə? əɹ dɪd jə min ði ʌðɝz? aɪ daʊt ðəɾ ɛɡwin wəd bi plizd ɪf aɪ dʒɹɑpt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɪn əɹ læp. ɛɡwin maɪt dʒʌs lɛt sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɡoʊ ən teɪk mi kæptɪv ɪnstɛd. fɔɹs mi tə nil bɪfɔɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝz dʒʌstəs ən dʒɛntəl mi dʒʌs tə ɡɪv əɹ ənʌðɝ nɑtʃ ɪn əɹ bɛlt."

Yes, Lews Therin said. We need to stay away from all of them. They refused to help us, you know. Refused! Said my plan was too reckless. That left me with only the Hundred Companions, no women to form a circle. Traitors! This is their fault. But . . . but I'm the one who killed Ilyena.

waɪ?

Why?

nɪneɪiv sɛd sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt ɹænd ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ. luz θɝɪn? hi sɛd tə ðə vɔɪs. wʌt wɑz ɪt jə dɪd? ðə wɪmən wʊdn hɛlp? waɪ?

Nynaeve said something, but Rand ignored her. Lews Therin? he said to the voice. What was it you did? The women wouldn't help? Why?

bʌt luz θɝɪn hæd bɪɡʌn sɑbɪŋ əɡɛn, ən ɪz vɔɪs ɡɹu dɪstənt.

But Lews Therin had begun sobbing again, and his voice grew distant.

"tɛl mi!" ɹænd jɛld, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪz kʌp daʊn. "bɝn ju, kɪnsleɪɝ! spik tə mi!"

"Tell me!" Rand yelled, throwing his cup down. "Burn you, Kinslayer! Speak to me!"

ðə ɹum fɛl saɪlənt.

The room fell silent.

ɹænd blɪŋkt. hid nɛvɝ . . . nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd spikɪŋ tə luz θɝɪn aʊt laʊd wɛɹ ʌðɝz kəd hɪɹ. ən ðeɪ nu. sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd spoʊkən ə ðə vɔɪs ðəɾ i hɝd, dɪsmɪsɪŋ ɹænd əz ɪf i wɝ ə kɑmən mædmæn.

Rand blinked. He'd never . . . never tried speaking to Lews Therin out loud where others could hear. And they knew. Semirhage had spoken of the voice that he heard, dismissing Rand as if he were a common madman.

ɹænd ɹitʃt ʌp, ɹʌnɪŋ ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. əɹ i tʃɹaɪd tə . . . bʌɾ i juz ði ɑɹm ðət wɑz oʊnli ə stʌmp, ən ɪɾ əkɑmplɪʃt nʌθɪŋ.

Rand reached up, running a hand through his hair. Or he tried to . . . but he used the arm that was only a stump, and it accomplished nothing.

laɪt! hi θɔt. aɪm luzɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl. hæf ðə taɪm, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɪtʃ vɔɪs ɪz maɪn ən wɪtʃ ɪz hɪz. ðɪs wɑz səpoʊz tə ɡɛt bɛɾɝ wən aɪ klɛnz seɪɾɪn! aɪ wɑz səpoʊz tə bi seɪf. . . .

Light! he thought. I'm losing control. Half the time, I don't know which voice is mine and which is his. This was supposed to get better when I cleansed saidin! I was supposed to be safe. . . .

nɑt seɪf, luz θɝɪn mʌɾɝd. wi wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi mæd. kæn tɝn bæk fɹəm ðət naʊ. hi bɪɡæn tə kækəl, bʌt ðə læftɝ tɝn tə sɑbz.

Not safe, Lews Therin muttered. We were already mad. Can't turn back from that now. He began to cackle, but the laughter turned to sobs.

ɹænd lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə ɹum. mɪnz dɑɹk aɪz wɝ soʊ wɝiɾ i hæd tə tɝn əweɪ. əliviə -  hu hæd wɑtʃt ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ əbaʊt sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɪð ðoʊz pɛnətʃɹeɪɾɪŋ aɪz ə hɝz - sim tu noʊɪŋ. nɪneɪiv faɪnəli ɡeɪv ɪn ən tʌɡd ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd. fəɹ wʌns, kædzueɪn dɪdn tʃæstaɪz ɪm fəɹ ɪz aʊtbɝst. ɪnstɛd ʃi dʒʌst sɪpt əɹ waɪn. haʊ kəd ʃi stæn ðə stʌf?

Rand looked around the room. Min's dark eyes were so worried he had to turn away. Alivia -  who had watched the exchange about Semirhage with those penetrating eyes of hers - seemed too knowing. Nynaeve finally gave in and tugged on her braid. For once, Cadsuane didn't chastise him for his outburst. Instead she just sipped her wine. How could she stand the stuff?

ðə θɔt wɑz tʃɹɪviəl. ɹɪdɪkjələs. hi wɑntəd tə læf. oʊnli, ðə saʊnd wʊdn kʌm aʊt. hi kʊdn sʌmən ivən ə ɹaɪ hjumɝ, nɑɾ ɛnimɔɹ. laɪt! aɪ kæn kip ðɪs ʌp. maɪ aɪz si əz ɪf ɪn ə fɑɡ, maɪ hæn ɪz bɝn əweɪ, ən ði oʊld wunz ɪn maɪ saɪd ɹɪp oʊpən ɪf aɪ də ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ stʃɹɛnjuəs ðən bɹið. aɪm dʒɹaɪ, laɪk ən oʊvɝjuzd wɛl. aɪ nid tə fɪnɪʃ maɪ wɝk hɪɹ ən ɡɛt tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

The thought was trivial. Ridiculous. He wanted to laugh. Only, the sound wouldn't come out. He couldn't summon even a wry humor, not anymore. Light! I can't keep this up. My eyes see as if in a fog, my hand is burned away, and the old wounds in my side rip open if I do anything more strenuous than breathe. I'm dry, like an overused well. I need to finish my work here and get to Shayol Ghul.

ʌðɝwaɪz, ðəɹ woʊn bi ɛniθɪŋ lɛft ə mi fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn tə kɪl.

Otherwise, there won't be anything left of me for the Dark One to kill.

ðət wɑzn ə θɔt tə kɑz læftɝ; ɪt wɑz wʌn tə kɑz dɪspɛɹ. bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt wip, fəɹ tɪɹz kəd nɑt kʌm fɹəm stil.

That wasn't a thought to cause laughter; it was one to cause despair. But Rand did not weep, for tears could not come from steel.

fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, luz θɝɪnz kɹaɪz simd ɪnʌf fəɹ boʊθ ə ðɛm.

For the moment, Lews Therin's cries seemed enough for both of them.

tʃæptɝ tu

CHAPTER 2

ðə neɪtʃɝ ə peɪn ɛɡwin stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, bæksaɪɾ əfleɪm wɪð ðə naʊ-fəmɪljɝ æɡəni ʌv ə sɑləd biɾɪŋ bɪniθ ðə hænz ə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. ʃi fɛlt laɪk ə ɹʌɡ ðət hæd dʒʌs bɪn paʊndɪd fɹi ʌv ɪts dʌst.

The Nature of Pain Egwene stood up straight, backside aflame with the now-familiar agony of a solid beating beneath the hands of the Mistress of Novices. She felt like a rug that had just been pounded free of its dust.

dɪspaɪt ðæt, ʃi kɑmli stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ waɪt skɝts, ðən tɝn tə ðə ɹumz mɪɹɝ ən kɑmli dæb ðə tɪɹz fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz. oʊnli wʌn tiɹ ɪn itʃ aɪ ðɪs taɪm. ʃi smaɪl tə hɝ ɹəflɛkʃən, ən əɹ twɪn sɛlvz nɑɾəd tə wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən.

Despite that, she calmly straightened her white skirts, then turned to the room's mirror and calmly dabbed the tears from the corners of her eyes. Only one tear in each eye this time. She smiled to her reflection, and her twin selves nodded to one another in satisfaction.

ə smɔl, dɑɹk-pænəld ɹum ɹəflɛktəd bɪhaɪn əɹ ɑn ðə mɪɹɝz sɪlvɝi sɝfəs. sətʃ ə stɝn pleɪs ɪt wɑz, ə stɝɾi stul ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ðə tɑp dɑɹkən ən smuð fɹəm jɪɹz ən jɪɹz ə jus.

A small, dark-paneled room reflected behind her on the mirror's silvery surface. Such a stern place it was, a sturdy stool in the corner, the top darkened and smoothed from years and years of use.

ə blɑkɪʃ dɛsk, sɛt wɪð ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz' θɪk toʊm. ðə nɛɹoʊ teɪbəl dɝɛkli bɪhaɪn ɛɡwin hæd səm kɑɹvɪŋz, bʌɾ ɪts lɛðɝ pæɾɪŋ wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ dɪstɪŋktɪv. mɛni ə nɑvəs - ən nɑɾ ə fju æksɛptɪd - hæd bɛn daʊn əkɹɔs ðət teɪbəl, bɛɹɪŋ ðə pʌnɪʃmən fəɹ dɪsəbiɾiəns. ɛɡwin kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪmædʒən ðət ðə teɪbəlz dɑɹk kʌlɝ hæd kʌm fɹəm ɹɪpiɾɪd tɝsteɪnz. mɛni ʌv əɹ oʊn hæd bɪn ʃɛd ðɛɹ.

A blockish desk, set with the Mistress of Novices' thick tome. The narrow table directly behind Egwene had some carvings, but its leather padding was far more distinctive. Many a novice - and not a few Accepted - had bent down across that table, bearing the punishment for disobedience. Egwene could almost imagine that the table's dark color had come from repeated tearstains. Many of her own had been shed there.

bʌt nʌn tədeɪ. oʊnli tu tɪɹz, ən niðɝ hæd fɔlən fɹəm əɹ tʃiks. nɑt ðət ʃi dɪdn hɝt;

But none today. Only two tears, and neither had fallen from her cheeks. Not that she didn't hurt;

hɝ ɪntaɪɝ bɑɾi sim tə bɝn fɹəm ðə peɪn. ɪndid, ðə sɪvɛɹɪɾi ʌv ðoʊz biɾɪŋz hæɾ ɪnkɹis ðə lɔŋɡɝ ʃi kəntɪnjud tə dɪfaɪ ðə paʊɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. bʌɾ əz ðə biɾɪŋz hæd ɡɹoʊn mɔɹ fɹikwən ən mɔɹ peɪnfəl, ɛɡwinz ɹizɑlv tə ɛndʒjʊɹ hæd ɡɹoʊn əz wɛl. ʃi hædn jɛt mænədʒ tə ɛmbɹeɪs ən æksɛp ðə peɪn əz ði il dɪd, bʌt ʃi fɛl ðət ʃi wɑz kloʊz. ði il kəd læf dʊɹɪŋ ðə moʊs kɹuəl ə tɔɹtʃɝz. wɛl, ʃi kəd smaɪl ðə moʊmənt ʃi stʊɾ ʌp.

her entire body seemed to burn from the pain. Indeed, the severity of those beatings had increased the longer she continued to defy the powers in the White Tower. But as the beatings had grown more frequent and more painful, Egwene's resolve to endure had grown as well. She hadn't yet managed to embrace and accept the pain as the Aiel did, but she felt that she was close. The Aiel could laugh during the most cruel of tortures. Well, she could smile the moment she stood up.

itʃ læʃ ʃi ɛndʒjʊɹd, itʃ peɪn ʃi sʌfɝd, wɑz ə vɪktɝi. ən vɪktɝi wɑz ɔlweɪz ə ɹizən fəɹ hæpinəs, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ wʌnz pɹaɪɾ əɹ wʌnz skɪn bɝnd.

Each lash she endured, each pain she suffered, was a victory. And victory was always a reason for happiness, no matter how one's pride or one's skin burned.

stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə teɪbəl bɪhaɪn ɛɡwin, ɹəflɛktəɾ ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ, wɑz ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz hɝsɛlf. sɪlviænə lʊk daʊn ət ðə lɛðɝ stʃɹæp ɪn əɹ hænz, fɹaʊnɪŋ. hɝ eɪdʒləs skwɛɹ feɪs sim dʒʌs feɪnli kənfjuzd; ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə stʃɹæp əz wʌn maɪɾ ə naɪf ðət ɹəfjuz tə kʌɾ əɹ ə læmp ðət ɹəfjuz tə laɪt.

Standing beside the table behind Egwene, reflected in the mirror, was the Mistress of Novices herself. Silviana looked down at the leather strap in her hands, frowning. Her ageless square face seemed just faintly confused; she regarded the strap as one might a knife that refused to cut or a lamp that refused to light.

ðə wʊmən wɑz ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, ə fækt ɹəflɛktəɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɪm ɑn ðə hɛm ə hɝ sɪmpəl ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs ən ðə fɹɪnd ʃɔl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ʃi wɑz tɔl ən stɑki ən ʃi hæɾ əɹ blæk hɛɹ bæk ɪn ə bʌn. ɪn moʊst weɪz ɛɡwin kənsɪɾɝd əɹ ə supɪɹiɝ mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. ivən ɪf ʃi hæɾ ədmɪnəstɝɾ ə ɹɪdɪkjələs nʌmbɝ ə pʌnɪʃməns tə ɛɡwin. pɝhæps kəz ə ðæt. sɪlviænə dɪɾ əɹ duɾi. laɪt nu ðəɹ wɝ fju ɪnʌf ɪn ðə taʊɝ leɪtli ʌv hum ðət kəd bi sɛd!

The woman was of the Red Ajah, a fact reflected in the trim on the hem of her simple gray dress and the fringed shawl on her shoulders. She was tall and stocky and she had her black hair back in a bun. In most ways Egwene considered her a superior Mistress of Novices. Even if she had administered a ridiculous number of punishments to Egwene. Perhaps because of that. Silviana did her duty. Light knew there were few enough in the Tower lately of whom that could be said!

sɪlviænə lʊkt ʌp ən mɛɾ ɛɡwinz aɪz ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ. ʃi kwɪkli pʊt daʊn ðə stʃɹæp ən wɑʃt ɔl ɪmoʊʃən fɹəm əɹ feɪs. ɛɡwin tɝn ɝaʊn kɑmli.

Silviana looked up and met Egwene's eyes in the mirror. She quickly put down the strap and washed all emotion from her face. Egwene turned around calmly.

ʌnkɛɹɪktɝɪstɪkli, sɪlviænə saɪd. "wɛn wɪl jə ɡɪv ðɪs ʌp, tʃaɪld?" ʃi æskt. "juv pɹuvən jəɹ pɔɪn kwaɪɾ ædmɝəbli, aɪ mʌst seɪ, bʌt jə mʌs noʊ ðəɾ əl kəntɪnju tə pʌnɪʃ jə əntɪl jə səbmɪt. pɹɑpɝ ɔɹɾɝ mʌs bi meɪnteɪnd."

Uncharacteristically, Silviana sighed. "When will you give this up, child?" she asked. "You've proven your point quite admirably, I must say, but you must know that I will continue to punish you until you submit. Proper order must be maintained."

ɛɡwin hɛld ɪn əɹ ʃɑk. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ɹɛɹli ədʒɹɛst ɛɡwin ɪksɛp tə ɔfɝ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən əɹ ɹipɹəbeɪʃən. stɪl, ðəɹ hæd bɪn kɹæks bɪfɔɹ. . . .

Egwene held in her shock. The Mistress of Novices rarely addressed Egwene except to offer instruction or reprobation. Still, there had been cracks before. . . .

"pɹɑpɝ ɔɹɾɝ, sɪlviænə?" ɛɡwin æskt. "æz ɪts bɪn meɪnteɪn ɛlswɛɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ?"

"Proper order, Silviana?" Egwene asked. "As it has been maintained elsewhere in the Tower?"

sɪlviænəz lɪps dʒɹu bæk ɪn ə laɪn. ʃi tɝn ən meɪɾ ə noʊteɪʃən ɪn əɹ bʊk. "aɪ wɪl si jə ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ɔf tə dɪnɝ wɪð ju."

Silviana's lips drew back in a line. She turned and made a notation in her book. "I will see you in the morning. Off to dinner with you."

ðə mɔɹnɪŋ pʌnɪʃmənt wəd bi kəz ɛɡwin hæd kɔl ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz baɪ hɝ neɪm wɪθaʊɾ æɾɪŋ ði ɑnɝɪfɪk "sədaɪ" tə ði ɛnd. ən laɪkli kəz boʊθ nu ðəɾ ɛɡwin wəd nɑt kɝtsi bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɛft.

The morning punishment would be because Egwene had called the Mistress of Novices by her name without adding the honorific "Sedai" to the end. And likely because both knew that Egwene would not curtsy before she left.

"aɪ wɪl ɹɪtɝn ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd, "bʌt dɪnɝ mʌst weɪt. aɪ hæv bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə ətɛn ɪleɪɾə ðɪs ivnɪŋ əz ʃi its." ðɪs sɛʃən wɪð sɪlviænə hæd ɡɔn lɔŋ - ɛɡwin hæd bɹɔt kwaɪɾ ə lɪst ʌv ɪnfɹækʃənz wɪð əɹ - ən naʊ ʃi wʊdn əv taɪm tə it. hɝ stʌmək kəmpleɪn ət ðə pɹɑspɛkt.

"I will return in the morning," Egwene said, "but dinner must wait. I have been ordered to attend Elaida this evening as she eats." This session with Silviana had gone long - Egwene had brought quite a list of infractions with her - and now she wouldn't have time to eat. Her stomach complained at the prospect.

sɪlviænə ʃoʊd dʒʌst ə bɹif moʊmən ʌv ɪmoʊʃən. wɑz ɪt sɝpɹaɪz? "æn jə sɛd nʌθɪŋ ə ðɪs ɝliɝ?"

Silviana showed just a brief moment of emotion. Was it surprise? "And you said nothing of this earlier?"

"wʊɾ ɪɾ əv tʃeɪnʒd ɛniθɪŋ ɪf aɪ hæd?"

"Would it have changed anything if I had?"

sɪlviænə dɪd nɑt ɹɪspɑn tə ðə kwɛstʃən. "ju wɪl iɾ æftɝ ətɛndɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn, ðɛn. aɪ ʃæl liv ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz fəɹ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə kɪtʃənz tə hoʊl jə səm fud. kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ ɔfən jə ɑɹ biɪŋ ɡɪvən hilɪŋ ðiz deɪz, tʃaɪld, jəl nid tə teɪk jəɹ milz. aɪ woʊn əv jə kəlæpsɪŋ fɹəm læk ə nɝɪʃmənt."

Silviana did not respond to the question. "You will eat after attending the Amyrlin, then. I shall leave instructions for the Mistress of the Kitchens to hold you some food. Considering how often you are being given Healing these days, child, you will need to take your meals. I won't have you collapsing from lack of nourishment."

stɝn, jɛt fɛɹ. ə pɪɾi ðɪs wʌn hæd faʊn əɹ weɪ tə ðə ɹɛd. "vɛɹi wɛl," ɛɡwin sɛd.

Stern, yet fair. A pity this one had found her way to the Red. "Very well," Egwene said.

"æn æftɝ iɾɪŋ," sɪlviænə sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ, "ju ʃæl ɹɪtɝn tə mi fəɹ ʃoʊɪŋ dɪsɹɪspɛk tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ʃiz nɛvɝ tə bi noʊn əz sɪmpli 'ɪleɪɾə' tə ju, tʃaɪld." ʃi tɝn daʊn tə hɝ lɛdʒɝ, æɾɪŋ, "bɪsaɪdz, laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz wʌt kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl jəl bi ɪn baɪ ðɪs ivnɪŋ."

"And after eating," Silviana said, raising a finger, "you shall return to me for showing disrespect to the Amyrlin Seat. She is never to be known as simply 'Elaida' to you, child." She turned down to her ledger, adding, "Besides, Light only knows what kind of trouble you'll be in by this evening."

əz ɛɡwin lɛf ðə smɔl tʃeɪmbɝ bɪhaɪnd - ɛntɝɪŋ ə waɪd, ɡɹeɪ-stoʊn hɔlweɪ wɪð flɔɹ taɪlz ʌv ɡɹin ən ɹɛd - ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ðət læs kɑmɛnt. pɝhæps ɪt hædn bɪn sɝpɹaɪz ðət sɪlviænə hæd ʃoʊn əpɑn hɪɹɪŋ ʌv ɛɡwinz vɪzət tə ɪleɪɾə. pɝhæps ɪt hæd bɪn sɪmpəθi. ɪleɪɾə wəd nɑt ɹiækt wɛl wən ɛɡwin stʊɾ ʌp tə hɝ ðə weɪ ʃi hæd tə ɔl ʌðɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ.

As Egwene left the small chamber behind - entering a wide, gray-stoned hallway with floor tiles of green and red - she considered that last comment. Perhaps it hadn't been surprise that Silviana had shown upon hearing of Egwene's visit to Elaida. Perhaps it had been sympathy. Elaida would not react well when Egwene stood up to her the way she had to all others in the Tower.

wɑz ðət waɪ sɪlviænə hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bɹɪŋ ɛɡwin bæk fəɹ ə faɪnəl stʃɹæpɪŋ æftɝ iɾɪŋ? wɪð ði ɔɹɾɝz sɪlviænə hæd ɡɪvən, ɛɡwin wəd bi ɹikwaɪɝd tə teɪk fud bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fəɹ əɹ pʌnɪʃmənt, ivən ɪf ɪleɪɾə hip ðə stʃɹæpɪŋz əpɑn hɝ.

Was that why Silviana had decided to bring Egwene back for a final strapping after eating? With the orders Silviana had given, Egwene would be required to take food before returning for her punishment, even if Elaida heaped the strappings upon her.

ɪt wɑz ə smɔl kaɪndnəs, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ɪt. ɛndʒjʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪli pʌnɪʃməns wɑz dɪfəkəlt ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt skɪpɪŋ milz.

It was a small kindness, but Egwene was grateful for it. Enduring the daily punishments was difficult enough without skipping meals.

əz ʃi pɑndɝd, tu ɹɛd sɪstɝz - keɪɾɝin ən bɑɹɑsin - əpɹoʊtʃt hɝ. keɪɾɝin hɛld ə bɹæs kʌp. ənʌðɝ doʊs ə fɔkɹut. ɪleɪɾə wɑntəd tə meɪk sɝɾən ðəɾ ɛɡwin kʊdn tʃænəl ə tʃɹɪkəl dʊɹɪŋ ðə mil, ɪt simd. ɛɡwin tʊk ðə kʌp wɪθaʊt pɹətɛstɪŋ ən daʊn ɪɾ ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl ɡʌlp, teɪstɪŋ ðə feɪnt, jɛt kɛɹəktɝɪstɪk, hɪn ə mɪnt. ʃi hændəd ðə kʌp bæk tə keɪɾɝin wɪð ən ɑfhændɪd dʒɛstʃɝ, ən ðə wʊmən hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə æksɛpt ɪt. ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ə ɹɔɪəl kʌbɛɹɝ.

As she pondered, two Red sisters - Katerine and Barasine - approached her. Katerine held a brass cup. Another dose of forkroot. Elaida wanted to make certain that Egwene couldn't channel a trickle during the meal, it seemed. Egwene took the cup without protesting and downed it in a single gulp, tasting the faint, yet characteristic, hint of mint. She handed the cup back to Katerine with an offhanded gesture, and the woman had no choice but to accept it. Almost as if she were a royal cupbearer.

ɛɡwin dɪdn hɛd fəɹ ɪleɪɾəz kɔɹɾɝz ɪmiɾiətli. ði oʊvɝli lɔŋ pʌnɪʃməns ɪntʃɹuʒən ɪndə ðə dɪnɝ aʊɝ aɪɹɑnɪkli lɛft əɹ wɪð ə fju spɛɹ moʊməns - ən ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə ɝaɪv ɝli, fəɹ ðət wəd ʃoʊ ɪleɪɾə dɛfɝəns. soʊ ɪnstɛd ʃi lɪŋɡɝɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə dɔɹ ə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz wɪð keɪɾɝin ən bɑɹɑsin. wəɾ ə sɝɾən fɪɡjɝ kʌm tə vɪzət ðə stʌɾi?

Egwene didn't head for Elaida's quarters immediately. The overly long punishment's intrusion into the dinner hour ironically left her with a few spare moments - and she didn't want to arrive early, for that would show Elaida deference. So instead she lingered outside the door of the Mistress of Novices with Katerine and Barasine. Would a certain figure come to visit the study?

ɪn ðə dɪstəns, smɔl klʌstɝz ə sɪstɝz wɔk ðə hɔlweɪz taɪlz ʌv ɡɹin ən ɹɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ə fɝɾɪv kæs tə ðɛɹ aɪz, laɪk hɛɹz vɛntʃɝɪŋ ɪndə ə klɪɹɪŋ tə nɪbəl ət livz, jɛt fɪɹɪŋ ðə pɹɛɾətɝ u hɪɾ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz. sɪstɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ ðiz deɪz ɔlweɪz wɔɹ ðɛɹ ʃɔlz, ən ðeɪ nɛvɝ wɛn əbaʊɾ əloʊn. səm ivən hɛl ðə paʊɝ, əz ɪf əfɹeɪɾ ə biɪŋ dʒʌmp baɪ fʊtpædz hɪɹ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf.

In the distance, small clusters of sisters walked the hallway's tiles of green and red. There was a furtive cast to their eyes, like hares venturing into a clearing to nibble at leaves, yet fearing the predator who hid in the shadows. Sisters in the Tower these days always wore their shawls, and they never went about alone. Some even held the Power, as if afraid of being jumped by footpads here in the White Tower itself.

"ɑɹ jə plizd wɪð ðɪs?" ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf æskɪŋ. ʃi ɡlænst ət keɪɾɝin ən bɑɹɑsin;

"Are you pleased with this?" Egwene found herself asking. She glanced at Katerine and Barasine;

boʊθ wɝ, koʊɪnsɪdɛntəli, ɔlsoʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹup ðət hæd fɝs kæptʃɝɾ ɛɡwin.

both were, coincidentally, also part of the group that had first captured Egwene.

"wʌt wɑz ðæt, tʃaɪld?" keɪɾɝin æskt kuli. "spikɪŋ tə ə sɪstɝ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ æskt ə kwɛstʃən fɝst? ɑɹ jə soʊ iɡɝ fəɹ mɔɹ pʌnɪʃmənt?" ʃi wɔɹ ə kənspɪkjuəs əmaʊn ə ɹɛd, hɝ dʒɹɛs ə bɹaɪt kɹɪmzən slæʃt wɪð blæk. hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ kɝl slaɪtli ɪn ɪts kæskeɪd daʊn əɹ bæk.

"What was that, child?" Katerine asked coolly. "Speaking to a sister without being asked a question first? Are you so eager for more punishment?" She wore a conspicuous amount of red, her dress a bright crimson slashed with black. Her dark hair curled slightly in its cascade down her back.

ɛɡwin ɪɡnɔɹd ðə θɹɛt. wʌt mɔɹ kəd ðeɪ də tə hɝ? "sɛɾ əsaɪd ðə bɪkɝɪŋ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, keɪɾɝin," ɛɡwin sɛd, wɑtʃɪŋ ə ɡɹup ə jɛloʊz pæs, ðɛɹ stɛp kwɪkənɪŋ əz ðeɪ sɔ ðə tu ɹɛdz. "sɛɾ əsaɪd ðə pɑstʃɝɪŋ fəɹ əθɔɹəɾi ən ðə θɹɛts. pʊt ðiz θɪŋz əweɪ ən lʊk. ɑɹ jə pɹaʊɾ ə ðɪs? ðə taʊɝ spɛn sɛntʃɝiz wɪθaʊɾ ən æmɪɝlɪn biɪŋ ɹeɪz fɹəm ðə ɹɛd. naʊ, wən jə faɪnəli hæv ə tʃæns, jəɹ tʃoʊzən liɾɝ əz dʌn ðɪs tə ðə taʊɝ. wɪmən u woʊn mit ði aɪz ə ðoʊz ðeɪ də nɑt noʊ fəmɪljɹli, sɪstɝz u tʃɹævəl ɪn klʌstɝz. ði ədʒəz bɪheɪv əz ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ət wɔɹ wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ!"

Egwene ignored the threat. What more could they do to her? "Set aside the bickering for a moment, Katerine," Egwene said, watching a group of Yellows pass, their step quickening as they saw the two Reds. "Set aside the posturing for authority and the threats. Put these things away and look. Are you proud of this? The Tower spent centuries without an Amyrlin being raised from the Red. Now, when you finally have a chance, your chosen leader has done this to the Tower. Women who won't meet the eyes of those they do not know familiarly, sisters who travel in clusters. The Ajahs behave as if they are at war with one another!"

keɪɾɝin snɪft ət ðə kɑmɛnt, ðoʊ ðə læŋki bɑɹɑsin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə ɡɹup ə jɛloʊz hɝiɪŋ daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm faɪɹɪŋ ɡlænsɪz bæk ət ðə tu ɹɛdz.

Katerine sniffed at the comment, though the lanky Barasine hesitated, glancing over her shoulder at the group of Yellows hurrying down the corridor, several of them firing glances back at the two Reds.

"ðɪs wɑz nɑt kɑz baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "ɪt wɑz kɹieɪɾəd baɪ jəɹ fulɪʃ ɹɛbəlz ən ðɛɹ bɪtʃɹeɪəl!"

"This was not caused by the Amyrlin," Katerine said. "It was created by your foolish rebels and their betrayal!"

maɪ ɹɛbəlz? ɛɡwin θɔt wɪð ən ɪnwɝd smaɪl. soʊ jə naʊ si ðɛm əz "maɪn," ɹæðɝ ðən ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ mi əz dʒʌst ə pʊɹ æksɛptɪɾ u wɑz dupt? ðæts pɹɑɡɹɛs.

My rebels? Egwene thought with an inward smile. So you now see them as "mine," rather than regarding me as just a poor Accepted who was duped? That's progress.

"wɝ wi ðə wʌnz u pʊl daʊn ə sɪɾɪŋ æmɪɝlɪn?" ɛɡwin æskt. "wɝ wi ðə wʌnz u tɝnd wɔɹɾɝ əɡɛnst wɔɹɾɝ, əɹ ðə wʌnz u feɪl tə kənteɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? hæv wi tʃoʊzən ən æmɪɝlɪn u ɪz soʊ paʊɝ-hʌŋɡɹi, ʃiz ɔɹɾɝd ðə kənstʃɹʌkʃən ə hɝ oʊn pæləs? ə wʊmən u hæz ɛvɹi sɪstɝ wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ʃɪl bi ðə nɛks tə bi stʃɹɪpt ə ðə ʃɔl?"

"Were we the ones who pulled down a sitting Amyrlin?" Egwene asked. "Were we the ones who turned Warder against Warder, or the ones who failed to contain the Dragon Reborn? Have we chosen an Amyrlin who is so power-hungry, she's ordered the construction of her own palace? A woman who has every sister wondering if she'll be the next to be stripped of the shawl?"

keɪɾɝin dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd, əz ðoʊ ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ʃi ʃʊdn bi dʒɹɔn ɪndə ən ɑɹɡjəmənt wɪð ə mɪɹ nɑvəs. bɑɹɑsin stɪl wɑtʃt ðə dɪstən jɛloʊz, hɝ aɪz waɪd. wɝid.

Katerine didn't respond, as though realizing that she shouldn't be drawn into an argument with a mere novice. Barasine still watched the distant Yellows, her eyes wide. Worried.

"aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ðæt ðə ɹɛd ʃəd nɑt bi ðə wʌnz ʃɛltɝɪŋ ɪleɪɾə, bʌt ʃəɾ ɪnstɛd pɹəvaɪɾ əɹ fɪɹsəs kɹɪɾɪks. fəɹ ɪleɪɾəz lɛɡəsi wɪl bi jəɹ oʊn. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt."

"I should think," Egwene said, "that the Red should not be the ones sheltering Elaida, but should instead provide her fiercest critics. For Elaida's legacy will be your own. Remember that."

keɪɾɝin ɡlænst ət hɝ, aɪz flɛɹɪŋ, ən ɛɡwin səpɹɛst ə kɹɪnʒ. pɝhæps ðət læs hæd bɪn tu stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd.

Katerine glanced at her, eyes flaring, and Egwene suppressed a cringe. Perhaps that last had been too straightforward.

"ju wɪl ɹipɔɹt tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz tənaɪt, tʃaɪld," keɪɾɝin ɪnfɔɹm hɝ. "æn ɪkspleɪn haʊ jə ʃoʊd dɪsɹɪspɛk tə sɪstɝz ən tə ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf."

"You will report to the Mistress of Novices tonight, child," Katerine informed her. "And explain how you showed disrespect to sisters and to the Amyrlin herself."

ɛɡwin hɛld əɹ tʌŋ. waɪ wɑz ʃi weɪstɪŋ əɹ taɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns ɹɛdz?

Egwene held her tongue. Why was she wasting her time trying to convince Reds?

ði eɪdʒɪd wʊɾən dɔɹ bɪhaɪn əɹ snæpt ʃʌt, meɪkɪŋ ɛɡwin dʒʌmp ən ɡlæns oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ðə tæpəstʃɹiz tə iðɝ saɪd stɝd slaɪtli, ðən wɛn stɪl. ɛɡwin hædn ɹilaɪz ðət ʃid lɛf ðə dɔɹ oʊpən dʒʌst ə kɹæk əz ʃid lɛft. hæd sɪlviænə lɪsən tə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən?

The aged wooden door behind her snapped shut, making Egwene jump and glance over her shoulder. The tapestries to either side stirred slightly, then went still. Egwene hadn't realized that she'd left the door open just a crack as she'd left. Had Silviana listened to the conversation?

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ taɪm tə dɔɾəl. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðəɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑzn gɑnə kʌm ðɪs ivnɪŋ.

There was no more time to dawdle. It appeared that Alviarin wasn't going to come this evening.

wɛɹ wɑz ʃi? ʃi ɔlweɪz ɝaɪv fəɹ pʌnɪʃmən ɹaɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə taɪm ðəɾ ɛɡwin fɪnɪʃt.

Where was she? She always arrived for punishment right around the time that Egwene finished.

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ðən stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. ðə tu ɹɛdz fɑloʊd - ðeɪ steɪd wɪð əɹ ɪnkɹisɪŋli naʊ, fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ, wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, əɾ ɔl taɪmz ɪksɛpt wən ɛɡwin vɪzəɾəd ðə kɔɹɾɝz ʌv ʌðɝ ədʒəz fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ækt əz ɪf ðoʊz tu sɪstɝz wɝ ən ɑnɝɛɹi ɹɛɾənu, ɹæðɝ ðən əɹ dʒeɪlɝz. ʃi ɔlsoʊ tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə peɪn ə hɝ bæksaɪd.

Egwene shook her head, then strode away down the hallway. The two Reds followed - they stayed with her increasingly now, following her, watching her, at all times except when Egwene visited the quarters of other Ajahs for training. She tried to act as if those two sisters were an honorary retinue, rather than her jailers. She also tried to ignore the pain of her backside.

ɔl saɪnz ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz wɪnɪŋ əɹ wɔɹ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə. ɝliɝ, ət lʌntʃ, ɛɡwin hæd hɝd ðə nɑvəsɪz ɡɑsəpɪŋ əbaʊt ðə dʒɹəmæɾɪk feɪljɝ ɪleɪɾə hæd sʌfɝɾ ɪn feɪlɪŋ tə kip ɹænd kæptʃɝd. ði ɪvɛnt wɑz sɛvɹəl mʌnθs pæst, naʊ, ən wɑz səpoʊz tə hæv bɪn sikɹət. ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz ðə ɹumɝ ʌv æʃəmən bɑndɪŋ sɪstɝz u hæd bɪn sɛn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm. ənʌðɝ mɪʃən ʌv ɪleɪɾəz ðət wɑzn səpoʊz tə bi noʊn. ɛɡwin hæd teɪkən stɛps tə kip ðiz feɪljɝz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə maɪnz ə ðə taʊɝz ɑkjəpəns, mʌtʃ əz ʃi hæd wɪð ɪleɪɾəz ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ tʃɹitmən ə ʃimɹɪn.

All signs indicated that Egwene was winning her war against Elaida. Earlier, at lunch, Egwene had heard the novices gossiping about the dramatic failure Elaida had suffered in failing to keep Rand captured. The event was several months past, now, and was supposed to have been secret. And then there was the rumor of Asha'man bonding sisters who had been sent to destroy them. Another mission of Elaida's that wasn't supposed to be known. Egwene had taken steps to keep these failures strong in the minds of the Tower's occupants, much as she had with Elaida's irregular treatment of Shemerin.

wʌtɛvɝ ðə nɑvəsɪz wɝ ɡɑsəpɪŋ əbaʊt, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ hɪɹɪŋ. jɛs, ɛɡwin wɑz wɪnɪŋ. bʌt ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə luz ðə sæɾəsfækʃən ʃid wʌns fɛlt ət ðət vɪktɝi. hu kəd teɪk dʒɔɪ ɪn siɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ənɹævəlɪŋ laɪk eɪdʒ kænvəs? hu kəd fil ɡlæd ðət tɑɹ vəlɑn, ðə ɡɹændəst ʌv ɔl ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz, wɑz paɪld wɪð ɹɛfjus? əz mʌtʃ əz ɛɡwin maɪt dɪspaɪz ɪleɪɾə, ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪɡzʌlt ət siɪŋ ən æmɪɝlɪn sit lɛd wɪð sətʃ ɪnkɑmpəɾəns.

Whatever the novices were gossiping about, the Aes Sedai were hearing. Yes, Egwene was winning. But she was beginning to lose the satisfaction she'd once felt at that victory. Who could take joy in seeing the Aes Sedai unraveling like aged canvas? Who could feel glad that Tar Valon, the grandest of all great cities, was piled with refuse? As much as Egwene might despise Elaida, she could not exult at seeing an Amyrlin Seat lead with such incompetence.

ən naʊ, tənaɪt, ʃi wəd feɪs ɪleɪɾə ɪn pɝsən. ɛɡwin wɔk sloʊli θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz, peɪsɪŋ hɝsɛlf soʊ əz tə nɑɾ ɝaɪv ɝli. haʊ ʃəd ʃi pɹəsiɾ ət ðə dɪnɝ? dʊɹɪŋ əɹ naɪn deɪz bæk ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ɛɡwin hæd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlɪmpst ɪleɪɾə. ətɛndɪŋ ðə wʊmən wəd bi deɪnʒɝəs. ɪf ʃi əfɛndəɾ ɪleɪɾə dʒʌst ə hɛɹ tu mʌtʃ, ʃi kəd faɪn hɝsɛlf biɪŋ sɛn fəɹ ɛksəkjuʃən.

And now, tonight, she would face Elaida in person. Egwene walked slowly through the hallways, pacing herself so as to not arrive early. How should she proceed at the dinner? During her nine days back in the Tower, Egwene had not so much as glimpsed Elaida. Attending the woman would be dangerous. If she offended Elaida just a hair too much, she could find herself being sent for execution.

ən jɛt, ʃi kəd nɑt sɪmpɝ ən pændɝ. ʃi wəd nɑt baʊ bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən, nɑɾ ɪf ɪt kɑst əɹ laɪf.

And yet, she could not simper and pander. She would not bow before the woman, not if it cost her life.

ɛɡwin tɝn ə kɔɹnɝ, ðən pʊld ʌp ʃɔɹt, nɪɹli stʌmbəlɪŋ. ðə hɔlweɪ ɛndəɾ əbɹʌpli ɪn ə stoʊnwɝk wɔl sɛt wɪð ə bɹaɪt taɪl mjʊɹəl. ði ɪmədʒ wɑz ðəɾ ʌv ən eɪntʃən æmɪɝlɪn, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ən ɔɹneɪt ɡoʊldən sit, hoʊldɪŋ fɔɹθ əɹ hæn ɪn wɔɹnɪŋ tə ðə kɪŋz ən kwinz ə ðə lænd. ðə plæk ət ðə bɑɾəm dɪklɛɹɾ ɪt tə bi ə dɪpɪkʃən ə kæɹeɪɡən mɑkɑnɝ, ɛndɪŋ ðə ɹɪbɛljən ɪn məsədʒɹɪn.

Egwene turned a corner, then pulled up short, nearly stumbling. The hallway ended abruptly in a stonework wall set with a bright tile mural.
