The image was that of an ancient Amyrlin, sitting on an ornate golden seat, holding forth her hand in warning to the kings and queens of the land. The plaque at the bottom declared it to be a depiction of Caraighan Maconar, ending the rebellion in Mosadorin.

ɛɡwin veɪɡli ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə mjʊɹəl; ðə læst ʃid sin ɪt, ɪt hæd bɪn ɑn ðə wɔl ə ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi. bʌt wən ʃid sin ɪt ðɛɹ, ði æmɪɝlɪnz feɪs hædn bɪn ə mæsk ə blʌd. ðə dɛd bɑɾiz dɪpɪktəd hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ði ivz hædn bɪn ðəɹ iðɝ.

Egwene vaguely recognized the mural; the last she'd seen it, it had been on the wall of the Tower library. But when she'd seen it there, the Amyrlin's face hadn't been a mask of blood. The dead bodies depicted hanging from the eaves hadn't been there either.

keɪɾɝin stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɛɡwin, feɪs pælɪŋ. noʊbɑdi laɪk tə spik ə ði ənnætʃɹəl weɪ ɹumz ən kɔɹɪɾɝz tʃeɪnʒd pleɪsəz ɪn ðə taʊɝ. ðə tʃɹænsfɝmeɪʃənz meɪd fəɹ ə sɑləm ɹimaɪndɝ ðət skwɑbəlz oʊvɝ əθɔɹəɾi wɝ sɛkəndɛɹi tə lɑɹdʒɝ, hɔɹəbəl tʃɹʌbəlz ɪn ðə wɝld. ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɛɡwin hæd sin nɑɾ oʊnli ə kɔɹəɾɝ muvd, bʌɾ ə dɪpɪkʃən ɔltɝɾ əz wɛl. ðə dɑɹk wʌn stɝd, ən ðə vɛɹi pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ.

Katerine stepped up beside Egwene, face paling. Nobody liked to speak of the unnatural way rooms and corridors changed places in the Tower. The transformations made for a solemn reminder that squabbles over authority were secondary to larger, horrible troubles in the world. This was the first time Egwene had seen not only a corridor moved, but a depiction altered as well. The Dark One stirred, and the very Pattern itself was shaking.

ɛɡwin tɝn ən stɔkt əweɪ fɹəm ðə mɪspleɪs mjʊɹəl. ʃi kʊdn foʊkəs ɑn ðoʊz pɹɑbləmz ɹaɪt naʊ. jə skɹʌbd ə flɔɹ klin baɪ fɝs pɪkɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl spɑɾ ən ɡɛɾɪŋ tə wɝk. ʃid pɪkt əɹ spɑt. ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd tə bi meɪd hoʊl.

Egwene turned and stalked away from the misplaced mural. She couldn't focus on those problems right now. You scrubbed a floor clean by first picking a single spot and getting to work. She'd picked her spot. The White Tower had to be made whole.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðɪs dɪtʊɹ wɑz gɑnə teɪk mɔɹ taɪm. ɛɡwin ɹɪlʌktənli heɪsən əɹ peɪs; ɪt wʊdn də tə bi ɝli, bʌt ʃid pɹəfɝ nɑt tə bi leɪɾ iðɝ. hɝ tu wɑtʃɝz hɝiɾ əz wɛl, skɝts swɪʃɪŋ əz ðeɪ bæktʃɹæk θɹu sɛvɹəl kɔɹɪɾɝz. əz ðeɪ dɪd, ɛɡwin kɑt saɪɾ ʌv ɑlviɛɝɪn hɝiɪŋ ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ, hɛd daʊn, wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə stʌɾi ʌv ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz.

Unfortunately, this detour was going to take more time. Egwene reluctantly hastened her pace; it wouldn't do to be early, but she'd prefer not to be late either. Her two watchers hurried as well, skirts swishing as they backtracked through several corridors. As they did, Egwene caught sight of Alviarin hurrying around a corner, head down, walking toward the study of the Mistress of Novices.

soʊ ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɝ pʌnɪʃmən æftɝ ɔl. wʌt hæd kɑzd əɹ tə dɪleɪ?

So she was going to her punishment after all. What had caused her to delay?

tu mɔɹ tɝnz ən wʌn flaɪɾ ə koʊl stoʊn stɛps leɪɾɝ, ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf kʌɾɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ sɛkʃən ə ðə taʊɝ, əz ðət naʊ pɹəvaɪɾəd ðə kwɪkɪst ɹuɾ ʌp tə ði æmɪɝlɪnz kɔɹɾɝz.

Two more turns and one flight of cold stone steps later, Egwene found herself cutting through the Red Ajah section of the Tower, as that now provided the quickest route up to the Amyrlin's quarters.

ɹɛd tæpəstʃɹiz hʌŋ ɑn ðə wɔlz, æksɛntɪd baɪ kɹɪmzən taɪlz ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðə wɪmən wɔkɪŋ ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz wɔɹ ɪkspɹɛʃənz ʌv ə nɪɹ junəfɔɹm ɔstɛɹɪɾi, ðɛɹ ʃɔlz dʒɹeɪp kɛɹfəli oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən ɑɹmz. hɪɹ, ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn ədʒɑz kɔɹɾɝz wɛɹ ðeɪ ʃəd bi kɑnfəɾənt, ðeɪ simd ɪnsəkjɝ ən səspɪʃəs, ivən ə ðoʊz sɝvəns u bʌsəld əbaʊt, bɛɹɪŋ ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts. ɛɡwin pæs θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz, wɪʃɪŋ ʃi dɪdn əv tə hɝi soʊ, əz ɪt meɪɾ əɹ lʊk kaʊd. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊɾ ɪt. ət ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə taʊɝ, ʃi klaɪm sɛvɹəl flaɪts ə stɛɹz, ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɹitʃɪŋ ðə hɔlweɪ ðət lɛd tə ði æmɪɝlɪnz kɔɹɾɝz.

Red tapestries hung on the walls, accented by crimson tiles on the floor. The women walking the corridors wore expressions of a near uniform austerity, their shawls draped carefully over their shoulders and arms. Here, in their own Ajah's quarters where they should be confident, they seemed insecure and suspicious, even of those servants who bustled about, bearing the Flame of Tar Valon on their chests. Egwene passed through the hallways, wishing she didn't have to hurry so, as it made her look cowed. There was nothing to be done about it. At the center of the Tower, she climbed several flights of stairs, eventually reaching the hallway that led to the Amyrlin's quarters.

hɝ bʌsaɪnəs wɪð nɑvəs tʃɔɹz ən lɛsənz hæd lɛft əɹ wɪð lɪɾəl taɪm tə kənsɪɾɝ əɹ kɑnfɹənteɪʃən wɪð ðə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn. ðɪs wɑz ðə wʊmən u hæd pʊl daʊn sɪuən, ðə wʊmən u hæd biɾən ɹænd, ən ðə wʊmən u hæd pʊʃt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðɛmsɛlvz tə ðə vɛɹi bɹɪŋk ə kəlæps. ɪleɪɾə niɾəd tə noʊ ɛɡwinz æŋɡɝ, ʃi niɾəd tə bi hjumɪlieɪɾɪd ən meɪɾ əʃeɪmd!

Her busyness with novice chores and lessons had left her with little time to consider her confrontation with the false Amyrlin. This was the woman who had pulled down Siuan, the woman who had beaten Rand, and the woman who had pushed the Aes Sedai themselves to the very brink of collapse. Elaida needed to know Egwene's anger, she needed to be humiliated and made ashamed!

ʃi. . . .

She. . . .

ɛɡwin stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪleɪɾəz ɡɪldɪd dɔɹ. noʊ.

Egwene stopped in front of Elaida's gilded door. No.

ʃi kəɾ ɪmædʒən ðə sin izəli. ɪleɪɾə ɛnɹeɪdʒd, ɛɡwin bænɪʃt tə ðə dɑɹk sɛlz bɪniθ ðə taʊɝ. wʌt ɡʊd wəd ðət du? ʃi kəd nɑt kənfɹʌn ðə wʊmən, nɑt jɛt. ðət wəɾ oʊnli lɛd tə moʊməntɛɹi sæɾəsfækʃən fɑloʊd baɪ ə dəbɪləteɪɾɪŋ feɪljɝ.

She could imagine the scene easily. Elaida enraged, Egwene banished to the dark cells beneath the Tower. What good would that do? She could not confront the woman, not yet. That would only lead to momentary satisfaction followed by a debilitating failure.

bʌt laɪt, ʃi kʊdn baʊ tə ɪleɪɾə iðɝ! ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪd noʊ sətʃ θɪŋ!

But light, she couldn't bow to Elaida either! The Amyrlin did no such thing!

əɹ . . . noʊ. ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪd wʌt wɑz ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə hɝ. wɪtʃ wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt? ðə waɪt taʊɝ, əɹ ɛɡwinz pɹaɪd? ði oʊnli weɪ tə wɪn ðɪs bæɾəl wɑz tə lɛɾ ɪleɪɾə θɪŋk ðət ʃi wɑz wɪnɪŋ. noʊ . . . noʊ, ði oʊnli weɪ tə wɪn wɑz tə lɛɾ ɪleɪɾə θɪŋk ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bæɾəl.

Or . . . no. The Amyrlin did what was required of her. Which was more important? The White Tower, or Egwene's pride? The only way to win this battle was to let Elaida think that she was winning. No . . . No, the only way to win was to let Elaida think there was no battle.

kəɾ ɛɡwin kip ə sɪvəl tʌŋ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə sɝvaɪv ðɪs naɪt? ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən.

Could Egwene keep a civil tongue long enough to survive this night? She wasn't certain.

haʊɛvɝ, ʃi niɾəd tə liv ðɪs dɪnɝ wɪð ɪleɪɾə filɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl, ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz pɹɑpɝli kaʊd. ðə bɛst weɪ tə ətʃiv ðət waɪl meɪnteɪnɪŋ səm mɛʒɝ ə pɹaɪd wəd bi tə seɪ nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl.

However, she needed to leave this dinner with Elaida feeling that she was in control, that Egwene was properly cowed. The best way to achieve that while maintaining some measure of pride would be to say nothing at all.

saɪləns. ðət wəd bi hɝ wɛpən ðɪs ivnɪŋ. stilɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ɛɡwin nɑkt.

Silence. That would be her weapon this evening. Steeling herself, Egwene knocked.

hɝ fɝst sɝpɹaɪz keɪm wən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. dɪdn ɪleɪɾə hæv sɝvəns tə pɝfɔɹm ðət fʌŋkʃən? ɛɡwin dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə sɪstɝ, bʌt ði eɪdʒləs feɪs wɑz ɑbviəs. ðə wʊmən wɑz ə ðə ɡɹeɪ, əz ɪndəkeɪɾəd baɪ hɝ ʃɔl, ən ʃi wɑz slɛndɝ wɪð ə fʊl bʌst. hɝ ɡoʊldən bɹaʊn hɛɹ fɛl tə ðə mɪɾəl ə hɝ bæk, ən ʃi hæɾ ə hɔntəd kæs tə hɝ aɪz, əz ɪf ʃid bɪn ʌndɝ ɡɹeɪt stʃɹeɪn ɹisənli.

Her first surprise came when an Aes Sedai opened the door. Didn't Elaida have servants to perform that function? Egwene didn't recognize the sister, but the ageless face was obvious. The woman was of the Gray, as indicated by her shawl, and she was slender with a full bust. Her golden brown hair fell to the middle of her back, and she had a haunted cast to her eyes, as if she'd been under great strain recently.

ɪleɪɾə sæɾ ɪnsaɪd. ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, lʊkɪŋ ɪn əɾ əɹ ɹaɪvəl fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɪð nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn tə hʌn ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ə tɝnɪŋ pɔɪn ðət simd ən ɪtɝnəɾi əɡoʊ. hænsəm ən stætʃuɛsk, ɪleɪɾə sim tə hæv lɔst ə smɔl mɛʒɝ ə hɝ stɝnnəs. ʃi sæt, sɪkjʊɹ ən smaɪlɪŋ feɪnli, əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn səm dʒoʊk ðəɾ oʊnli ʃi ʌndɝstʊd.

Elaida sat inside. Egwene hesitated in the doorway, looking in at her rival for the first time since departing from the White Tower with Nynaeve and Elayne to hunt the Black Ajah, a turning point that seemed an eternity ago. Handsome and statuesque, Elaida seemed to have lost a small measure of her sternness. She sat, secure and smiling faintly, as if thinking on some joke that only she understood.

hɝ tʃɛɹ wɑz ɔlmoʊst ə θɹoʊn, kɑɹvd, ɡɪldɪɾ ən peɪntəd wɪð ɹɛɾ ən waɪt. ðəɹ wɑz ə sɛkən pleɪs sɛɾ ət ðə teɪbəl, pɹəzuməbli fəɹ ðə neɪmləs ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ.

Her chair was almost a throne, carved, gilded and painted with red and white. There was a second place set at the table, presumably for the nameless Gray sister.

ɛɡwin hæd nɛvɝ vɪzəɾəd ən æmɪɝlɪnz oʊn kɔɹɾɝz bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ʃi kəɾ ɪmædʒən wʌt sɪuənz maɪɾ əv lʊk laɪk. sɪmpəl, jɛt nɑt stɑɹk. dʒʌst ɪnʌf ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən tə ɪndəkeɪt ðət ðɪs wɑz ðə ɹum ə sʌmwʌn ɪmpɔɹɾənt, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə bɪkʌm ə dɪstʃɹækʃən. ʌndɝ sɪuən, ɛvɹiθɪŋ wʊɾə sɝvd ə fʌŋkʃən - pɝhæps sɛvɹəl fʌŋkʃənz ət wʌns. teɪbəlz wɪð hɪɾən kəmpɑɹtməns. wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz ðət dʌbəld əz mæps. kɹɔst sɔɹdz oʊvɝ ðə hɑɹθ ðət wɝ ɔɪld, ʃəd ðə wɔɹɾɝz nid ðɛm.

Egwene had never visited an Amyrlin's own quarters before, but she could imagine what Siuan's might have looked like. Simple, yet not stark. Just enough ornamentation to indicate that this was the room of someone important, but not enough to become a distraction. Under Siuan, everything would have served a function - perhaps several functions at once. Tables with hidden compartments. Wall hangings that doubled as maps. Crossed swords over the hearth that were oiled, should the Warders need them.

əɹ pɝhæps ðət wɑz dʒʌs fænsi. ɹəɡɑɹdləs, nɑɾ oʊnli hæɾ ɪleɪɾə teɪkən dɪfɹən ɹumz fəɹ əɹ kɔɹɾɝz; hɝ dɛkɝeɪʃənz wɝ noʊɾəbli ɹɪtʃ. ði ɪntaɪɝ swit hædn bɪn dɛkɝeɪɾəd jɛt - ðəɹ wɑz tɔk ðət ʃi wɑz æɾɪŋ tə hɝ ɹumz deɪ baɪ deɪ - bʌt wʌt wɑz ðəɹ wɑz vɛɹi lævɪʃ. nu sɪlk bɹoʊkeɪdz, ɔl ə ɹɛd, hʌŋ fɹəm ðə wɔlz ən silɪŋz. ðə tɛɹən ɹʌɡ ʌndɝfʊt dɪpɪktəd bɝdz əflaɪt, ən wɑz soʊ faɪnli woʊvən ðəɾ ɪt kəɾ ɔlmoʊs bi mɪsteɪkən fəɹ ə peɪntɪŋ. skæɾɝd θɹu ðə ɹum wɝ pisəz ə fɝnɪtʃɝ ʌv ə dʌzən dɪfɹən staɪlz ən meɪks, itʃ wʌn lævɪʃli kɑɹvd ən ɪnleɪd wɪð aɪvɝi. hɪɹ ə sɪɹiz ə vaɪnz, ðəɹ ə nɑbi ɹɪdʒ dɪzaɪn, ðəɹ kɹɪskɹɔsɪŋ sɝpəns.

Or perhaps that was just fancy. Regardless, not only had Elaida taken different rooms for her quarters; her decorations were notably rich. The entire suite hadn't been decorated yet - there was talk that she was adding to her rooms day by day - but what was there was very lavish. New silk brocades, all of red, hung from the walls and ceilings. The Tairen rug underfoot depicted birds aflight, and was so finely woven that it could almost be mistaken for a painting. Scattered through the room were pieces of furniture of a dozen different styles and makes, each one lavishly carved and inlaid with ivory. Here a series of vines, there a knobby ridged design, there crisscrossing serpents.

mɔɹ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ ðən ði ɪkstʃɹævəɡəns wɑz ðə stoʊl əkɹɔs ɪleɪɾəz ʃoʊldɝz. ɪt wɑz stʃɹaɪpt wɪð sɪks kʌlɝz. nɑt sɛvən, bʌt sɪks! ðoʊ ɛɡwin hæd nɑt tʃoʊzən ən ədʒɑ hɝsɛlf, ʃi wʊɾə teɪkən ðə ɡɹin. bʌt ðət dɪdn stɑp əɹ fɹəm filɪŋ ə sɝdʒ ʌv æŋɡɝ ət siɪŋ ðət ʃɔl wɪð blu ɹimuvd. wʌn dɪd nɑt sɪmpli dɪsbænd wʌn ə ði ədʒəz, ivən ɪf wʌn wɝ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit!

More infuriating than the extravagance was the stole across Elaida's shoulders. It was striped with six colors. Not seven, but six! Though Egwene had not chosen an Ajah herself, she would have taken the Green. But that didn't stop her from feeling a surge of anger at seeing that shawl with blue removed. One did not simply disband one of the Ajahs, even if one were the Amyrlin Seat!

bʌɾ ɛɡwin hɛld əɹ tʌŋ. ðɪs miɾɪŋ wɑz əbaʊt sɝvaɪvəl. ɛɡwin kəd bɛɹ stʃɹæps ə peɪn fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ. kəd ʃi bɛɹ ɪleɪɾəz ɛɹəɡəns əz wɛl?

But Egwene held her tongue. This meeting was about survival. Egwene could bear straps of pain for the good of the Tower. Could she bear Elaida's arrogance as well?

"noʊ kɝtsi?" ɪleɪɾə æskt əz ɛɡwin ɛntɝd ðə ɹum. "ðeɪ sɛd ðət jə wɝ stʌbɝn. wɛl, ðɛn, jə ʃæl vɪzət ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz wən ðɪs sʌpɝ ɪz θɹu ən ɪnfɔɹm əɹ ə ðə læps.

"No curtsy?" Elaida asked as Egwene entered the room. "They said that you were stubborn. Well, then, you shall visit the Mistress of Novices when this supper is through and inform her of the lapse.

wʌt dʒju seɪ tə ðæt?"

What do you say to that?"

ðət jə ɑɹ ə pleɪɡ əpɑn ðɪs stʃɹʌktʃɝ əz vaɪl ən dɪstʃɹʌktɪv əz ɛni dɪziz ðəɾ əz stʃɹʌk sɪɾi ən pipəl ɪn ɔl jɪɹz pæst. ðət jə -  ɛɡwin bɹoʊk əɹ ɡeɪz əweɪ fɹəm ɪleɪɾəz. ən - filɪŋ ðə ʃeɪm ʌv ɪt vaɪbɹeɪt θɹu hɝ vɛɹi boʊnz - ʃi baʊɾ əɹ hɛd.

That you are a plague upon this structure as vile and destructive as any disease that has struck city and people in all years past. That you -  Egwene broke her gaze away from Elaida's. And - feeling the shame of it vibrate through her very bones - she bowed her head.

ɪleɪɾə læft, ɑbviəsli teɪkɪŋ ðə dʒɛstʃɝ ðə ɹaɪt weɪ. "ɑnəsli, aɪ ɪkspɛktəd jə tə bi mɔɹ tʃɹʌbəl. ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðət sɪlviænə dʌz noʊ hɝ duɾi. ðəɾ ɪz wɛl; aɪ hæd wɝid ðət ʃi, laɪk fɑɹ tu mɛni ɪn ðə taʊɝ leɪtli, hæd bɪn ʃɝkɪŋ. wɛl, bi bɪzi wɪð ju. aɪ woʊnt weɪɾ ɔl naɪt tə daɪn."

Elaida laughed, obviously taking the gesture the right way. "Honestly, I expected you to be more trouble. It appears that Silviana does know her duty. That is well; I had worried that she, like far too many in the Tower lately, had been shirking. Well, be busy with you. I won't wait all night to dine."

ɛɡwin klɛntʃt əɹ fɪsts, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ðə bæk wɔl wɑz sɛt wɪð ə lɔŋ sɝvɪŋ teɪbəl bɛɹɪŋ sɛvɹəl sɪlvɝ plæɾɝz, ðɛɹ pɑlɪʃt doʊm lɪdz dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɪð kɑndənseɪʃən fɹəm ðə hiɾəd kɑntɛns. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlsoʊ ə sɪlvɝ sup tʃɹin. tə ðə saɪd, ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ hʌvɝd nɪɹ ðə dɔɹ.

Egwene clenched her fists, but said nothing. The back wall was set with a long serving table bearing several silver platters, their polished domed lids dripping with condensation from the heated contents. There was also a silver soup tureen. To the side, the Gray sister hovered near the door.

laɪt! ðə wʊmən wɑz tɛɹəfaɪd. ɛɡwin hæd ɹɛɹli sin sətʃ ən ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ə sɪstɝ. wʌt wɑz kɑzɪŋ ɪt?

Light! The woman was terrified. Egwene had rarely seen such an expression on a sister. What was causing it?

"kʌm, maɪdɑni," ɪleɪɾə sɛd tə ðə ɡɹeɪ. "ɑɹ jə gɑnə hʌvɝ ɔl naɪt? sɪt daʊn!"

"Come, Meidani," Elaida said to the Gray. "Are you going to hover all night? Sit down!"

ɛɡwin kʌvɝɾ ə moʊmən ə ʃɑk. maɪdɑni? ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz sɛn baɪ ʃɛɹiəm ən ði ʌðɝz tə spaɪ ɑn ðə waɪt taʊɝ! əz ɛɡwin tʃɛk ðə kɑntɛns ʌv itʃ plæɾɝ, ʃi ʃɑɾ ə ɡlæns oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. maɪdɑni hæd faʊn əɹ weɪ tə ðə smɔl, lɛs ɔɹneɪt siɾ əɾ ɪleɪɾəz saɪd. dɪd ðə ɡɹeɪ ɔlweɪz wɛɹ sətʃ faɪnɝi tə sʌpɝ? hɝ nɛk spɑɹkəld wɪð ɛmɹəlz ən əɹ mjuɾɪd ɡɹin dʒɹɛs wɑz ə ðə moʊst ɪkspɛnsɪv sɪlk, æksɛntʃəweɪɾɪŋ ə bʊzəm ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ævɝɪdʒ ɑn ənʌðɝ wʊmən, bʌt ðət simd æmpəl ɑn maɪdɑniz slɛndɝ bɑɾi.

Egwene covered a moment of shock. Meidani? She was one of those sent by Sheriam and the others to spy on the White Tower! As Egwene checked the contents of each platter, she shot a glance over her shoulder. Meidani had found her way to the small, less ornate seat at Elaida's side. Did the Gray always wear such finery to supper? Her neck sparkled with emeralds and her muted green dress was of the most expensive silk, accentuating a bosom that might have been average on another woman, but that seemed ample on Meidani's slender body.

bioʊnɪn sɛd ʃid wɔɹn ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝz ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə nu ðeɪ wɝ spaɪz. soʊ waɪ hædn maɪdɑni flɛd ðə taʊɝ? wʌt wɑz hoʊldɪŋ əɹ hɪɹ?

Beonin said she'd warned the Gray sisters that Elaida knew they were spies. So why hadn't Meidani fled the Tower? What was holding her here?

wɛl, ət lis naʊ ðə wʊmənz ɪkspɹɛʃən ə tɛɹɝ meɪd sɛns. "maɪdɑni," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, sɪpɪŋ fɹəm ə ɡɑbləɾ ʌv waɪn, "ju ɑɹ ɹæðɝ wɑn ðɪs deɪ. hæv jə bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪnʌf sʌn?"

Well, at least now the woman's expression of terror made sense. "Meidani," Elaida said, sipping from a goblet of wine, "you are rather wan this day. Have you been getting enough sun?"

"aɪ hæv bɪn spɛndɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm wɪð hɪstɔɹɪkəl ɹɛkɝdz, ɪleɪɾə," maɪdɑni sɛd, vɔɪs ənivən. "hæv jə fɝɡɑɾən?"

"I have been spending a great deal of time with historical records, Elaida," Meidani said, voice uneven. "Have you forgotten?"

"ɑ, ðəɾ ɪz ɹaɪt," ɪleɪɾə sɛd mjuzɪŋli. "ɪt wɪl bi ɡʊd tə noʊ haʊ tʃɹeɪɾɝz əv bɪn tʃɹiɾəd ɪn ðə pæst. bɪhɛɾɪŋ simz tu izi ən sɪmpəl ə pʌnɪʃmən tə mi. ðoʊz u splɪɾ əɹ taʊɝ, ðoʊz u flɔn ðɛɹ dɪfɛkʃən, ə vɛɹi spɛʃəl ɹɪwɔɹd wɪl bi niɾəd fəɹ ðɛm. wɛl, kəntɪnju jəɹ sɝtʃ ðɛn."

"Ah, that is right," Elaida said musingly. "It will be good to know how traitors have been treated in the past. Beheading seems too easy and simple a punishment to me. Those who split our Tower, those who flaunt their defection, a very special reward will be needed for them. Well, continue your search then."

maɪdɑni sæt daʊn, hænz ɪn læp. ɛniwʌn ʌðɝ ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wʊɾə hæd tə mɑp əɹ bɹaʊ fɹi ʌv swɛt. ɛɡwin stɝd ðə sɪlvɝ tʃɹin, hæn klʌtʃɪŋ ðə leɪɾəl wɪð ə waɪt-nʌkəld ɡɹɪp. ɪleɪɾə nu. ʃi nu ðət maɪdɑni wɑz ə spaɪ, ən jɛt ʃi stɪl ɪnvaɪɾəd ðə wʊmən tə dɪnɝ. tə pleɪ wɪð hɝ.

Meidani sat down, hands in lap. Anyone other than an Aes Sedai would have had to mop her brow free of sweat. Egwene stirred the silver tureen, hand clutching the ladle with a white-knuckled grip. Elaida knew. She knew that Meidani was a spy, and yet she still invited the woman to dinner. To play with her.

"hɝi ʌp, ɡɝl," ɪleɪɾə snæpt əɾ ɛɡwin.

"Hurry up, girl," Elaida snapped at Egwene.

ɛɡwin plʌkt ʌp ðə tʃɹin, ðə hændəlz wɔɹm bɪniθ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ən wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ðə smɔl teɪbəl. ʃi fɪl ðə boʊlz wɪð ə bɹaʊnɪʃ bɹɔθ bɑbɪŋ wɪð kwinz kɹaʊn mʌʃɹumz. ɪt smɛl soʊ hɛvəli pɛpɝd ðəɾ ɛni ʌðɝ fleɪvɝ wəd bi ɪndɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl. soʊ mʌtʃ fud hæd ɡɔn bæd ðət wɪθaʊt spaɪs, ðə sup wəd bi ɪnɛɾəbəl.

Egwene plucked up the tureen, the handles warm beneath her fingers, and walked over to the small table. She filled the bowls with a brownish broth bobbing with Queen's Crown mushrooms. It smelled so heavily peppered that any other flavor would be indistinguishable. So much food had gone bad that without spice, the soup would be inedible.

ɛɡwin wɝk məkænɪkli, laɪk ə wæɡən wil ɹoʊlɪŋ bɪhaɪn ði ɑksən. ʃi dɪdn əv tə meɪk tʃɔɪsəz; ʃi dɪdn əv tə ɹɪspɑnd. ʃi dʒʌst wɝkt. ʃi fɪl ðə sup boʊlz pɹɪsaɪsli, ðən fɛtʃt ðə bɹɛd bæskəɾ ən pleɪst wʌn pis - nɑt tu kɹʌsti - ɑn itʃ smɔl pɔɹsələn bɹɛd sɔsɝ. ʃi ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ə sɝkjəlɝ dæb ə bʌɾɝ fəɹ itʃ, kʌt kwɪkli bʌt pɹɪsaɪsli fɹəm ðə lɑɹdʒɝ bɹɪk wɪð ə kʌpəl ə flɪks ə ðə naɪf. wʌn dɪd nɑt spɛn lɔŋ əz ən ɪnkipɝz dɔɾɝ wɪθaʊt lɝnɪŋ tə sɝv ə pɹɑpɝ mil.

Egwene worked mechanically, like a wagon wheel rolling behind the oxen. She didn't have to make choices; she didn't have to respond. She just worked. She filled the soup bowls precisely, then fetched the bread basket and placed one piece - not too crusty - on each small porcelain bread saucer. She returned with a circular dab of butter for each, cut quickly but precisely from the larger brick with a couple of flicks of the knife. One did not spend long as an innkeeper's daughter without learning to serve a proper meal.

ivən əz ʃi wɝkt, ʃi stud. itʃ stɛp wɑz æɡəni, ən nɑt kəz ə hɝ stɪl-bɝnɪŋ bæksaɪd. ðət fɪzɪkəl peɪn, ɑdli, simd ɪnsɪɡnjɪfɪkənt naʊ. ɪt wɑz sɛkəndɛɹi tə ðə peɪn ə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ saɪlənt, ðə peɪn ə nɑɾ əlaʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə kənfɹʌn ðɪs ɑfəl wʊmən, soʊ ɹiɡəl, soʊ ɛɹəɡənt.

Even as she worked, she stewed. Each step was agony, and not because of her still-burning backside. That physical pain, oddly, seemed insignificant now. It was secondary to the pain of remaining silent, the pain of not allowing herself to confront this awful woman, so regal, so arrogant.

əz ðə tu wɪmən bɪɡæn ðɛɹ sup - pɔɪntɪdli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə wivəlz ɪn ðɛɹ bɹɛd - ɛɡwin ɹitʃɹiɾəd tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum ən stʊd, hænz klæsp bɪfɔɹ hɝ, pɑstʃɝ stɪf. ɪleɪɾə ɡlænst ət hɝ, ðən smaɪld, əpɛɹənli siɪŋ ənʌðɝ saɪn ə səbsɝviəns. ɪn ɹiæləɾi, ɛɡwin dɪdn tʃɹʌs hɝsɛlf tə muv, fəɹ ʃi fɪɹd ðəɾ ɛni æktɪvəɾi wəɾ ɛnd wɪð əɹ slæpɪŋ ɪleɪɾə əkɹɔs ðə feɪs.

As the two women began their soup - pointedly ignoring the weevils in their bread - Egwene retreated to the side of the room and stood, hands clasped before her, posture stiff. Elaida glanced at her, then smiled, apparently seeing another sign of subservience. In reality, Egwene didn't trust herself to move, for she feared that any activity would end with her slapping Elaida across the face.

laɪt, bʌt ðɪs wɑz hɑɹd!

Light, but this was hard!

"wʌt tɔk ɪz ðəɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, maɪdɑni?" ɪleɪɾə æskt, dɪpɪŋ əɹ bɹɛɾ ɪn ðə sup.

"What talk is there in the Tower, Meidani?" Elaida asked, dipping her bread in the soup.

"aɪ . . . doʊn əv mʌtʃ taɪm tə lɪsən. . . ."

"I . . . don't have much time to listen. . . ."

ɪleɪɾə lin fɔɹwɝd. "oʊ, ʃʊɹli jə noʊ sʌmθɪŋ. juv ɪɹz, ən ivən ɡɹeɪz mʌst ɡɑsəp. wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ seɪɪŋ əbaʊt ðoʊz ɹɛbəlz?"

Elaida leaned forward. "Oh, surely you know something. You have ears, and even Grays must gossip. What are they saying about those rebels?"

maɪdɑni peɪl fɝðɝ. "aɪ . . . aɪ . . ."

Meidani paled further. "I . . . I . . ."

"m," ɪleɪɾə sɛd. "wɛn wi wɝ nɑvəsɪz, aɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ jə biɪŋ soʊ sloʊ ʌv wɪt, maɪdɑni. jə hævən ɪmpɹɛs mi ðiz læs fju wiks; aɪ bɪɡɪn tə wʌndɝ waɪ jə wɝ ɛvɝ ɡɪvən ðə ʃɔl. pɝhæps ɪt nɛvɝ bɪlɔŋd ɑn jəɹ ʃoʊldɝz ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs."

"Hmm," Elaida said. "When we were novices, I don't remember you being so slow of wit, Meidani. You haven't impressed me these last few weeks; I begin to wonder why you were ever given the shawl. Perhaps it never belonged on your shoulders in the first place."

maɪdɑniz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd.

Meidani's eyes opened wide.

ɪleɪɾə smaɪld ət hɝ. "oʊ, aɪm oʊnli tizɪŋ ju, tʃaɪld. bæk tə jəɹ mil."

Elaida smiled at her. "Oh, I'm only teasing you, child. Back to your meal."

ʃi dʒoʊkt! dʒoʊkt əbaʊt haʊ ʃi hæd stoʊlən ðə ʃɔl fɹəm ə wʊmən, hjumɪlieɪɾɪŋ əɹ tə sətʃ ən ɪkstɛn ðət ʃi flɛd ðə taʊɝ. laɪt! wʌt hæd hæpən tə ɪleɪɾə? ɛɡwin hæd mɛt ðɪs wʊmən bɪfɔɹ, ən ɪleɪɾə hæd stʃɹʌk əɹ əz stɝn, bʌt nɑt tɝænɪkəl. paʊɝ tʃeɪnʒd pipəl. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðəɾ ɪn ɪleɪɾəz keɪs, hoʊldɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæd teɪkən əɹ stɝnnəs ən səlɛmnəɾi ən ɹipleɪst əm wɪð ə hɛɾi sɛns ʌv ɛntaɪɾəlmənt ən kɹulti.

She joked! Joked about how she had stolen the shawl from a woman, humiliating her to such an extent that she fled the Tower. Light! What had happened to Elaida? Egwene had met this woman before, and Elaida had struck her as stern, but not tyrannical. Power changed people. It appeared that in Elaida's case, holding the Amyrlin Seat had taken her sternness and solemnity and replaced them with a heady sense of entitlement and cruelty.

maɪdɑni lʊkt ʌp. "aɪ . . . aɪ hæv hɝd sɪstɝz ɪkspɹɛs wɝi əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn."

Meidani looked up. "I . . . I have heard sisters express worry about the Seanchan."

ɪleɪɾə weɪvd ən ɪndɪfɹən hænd, sɪpɪŋ əɹ sup. "bɑ. ðeɪ ɑɹ tu dɪstən tə bi ʌv deɪnʒɝ tə ʌs. aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ðəɹ sikɹɪtli wɝkɪŋ fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. iðɝ weɪ, aɪ səspɛk ðət ðə ɹumɝz əbaʊɾ əm ɑɹ lɑɹdʒli ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd." ɪleɪɾə ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin. "ɪts ə sɔɹs ə kɑnstən əmjuzmən tə mi ðət səm wɪl bɪliv ɛniθɪŋ ðət ðeɪ hɪɹ."

Elaida waved an indifferent hand, sipping her soup. "Bah. They are too distant to be of danger to us. I wonder if they're secretly working for the Dragon Reborn. Either way, I suspect that the rumors about them are largely exaggerated." Elaida glanced at Egwene. "It's a source of constant amusement to me that some will believe anything that they hear."

ɛɡwin kʊdn spik. ʃi kəd bɛɹli hæv spʌɾɝd. haʊ wəɾ ɪleɪɾə fil əbaʊt ðiz "ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd" ɹumɝz ɪf ðə sintʃæn slæpt ə koʊld æɾəm ɝaʊn əɹ ɪɾiət nɛk? ɛɡwin kəd səmtaɪmz fil ðət bæn ɑn əɹ oʊn skɪn, ɪtʃɪŋ, ɪmpɑsəbəl tə muv. səmtaɪmz, ɪt stɪl meɪɾ əɹ feɪnli sɪk tə muv ɝaʊn fɹili, əz ɪf ʃi fɛl ðət ʃi ʃəd bi lɑkt əweɪ, tʃeɪn tə ðə poʊst ɑn ðə wɔl baɪ ə sɪmpəl lup ə mɛɾəl.

Egwene couldn't speak. She could barely have sputtered. How would Elaida feel about these "exaggerated" rumors if the Seanchan slapped a cold a'dam around her idiot neck? Egwene could sometimes feel that band on her own skin, itching, impossible to move. Sometimes, it still made her faintly sick to move around freely, as if she felt that she should be locked away, chained to the post on the wall by a simple loop of metal.

ʃi nu wʌt ʃi hæd dʒɹimd, ən nu ðoʊz dʒɹimz tə bi pɹəfɛɾɪk. ðə sintʃæn wəd stʃɹaɪk ət ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. ɪleɪɾə, ɑbviəsli, dɪskaʊntɪɾ əɹ wɔɹnɪŋz.

She knew what she had dreamed, and knew those dreams to be prophetic. The Seanchan would strike at the White Tower itself. Elaida, obviously, discounted her warnings.

"noʊ," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, weɪvɪŋ fəɹ ɛɡwin tə bɹɪŋ ənʌðɝ leɪɾəl ə sup. "ðiz sintʃæn ɑɹ nɑt ðə pɹɑbləm. ðə ɹil deɪnʒɝ ɪz ðə kəmplit læk ʌv oʊbiɾiəns ʃoʊn baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. wʌt wɪl aɪ hæv tə də tə ɛn ðoʊz fulɪʃ tɔks ət ðə bɹɪdʒəz? haʊ mɛni sɪstɝz wɪl əv tə də pɛnəns bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ æknɑlɪdʒ maɪ əθɔɹəɾi?" ʃi sæt, tæpɪŋ əɹ spun əɡɛnst əɹ sup kʌp. ɛɡwin, ət ðə sɝvɪŋ teɪbəl, pɪkt ʌp ðə tʃɹin, ɹitʃɹivɪŋ ðə leɪɾəl fɹəm ɪts sɪlvɝ hoʊldɝ.

"No," Elaida said, waving for Egwene to bring another ladle of soup. "These Seanchan are not the problem. The real danger is the complete lack of obedience shown by the Aes Sedai. What will I have to do to end those foolish talks at the bridges? How many sisters will have to do penance before they acknowledge my authority?" She sat, tapping her spoon against her soup cup. Egwene, at the serving table, picked up the tureen, retrieving the ladle from its silver holder.

"jɛs," ɪleɪɾə mjuzd, "ɪf ðə sɪstɝz hæd bɪn oʊbiɾiənt, ðən ðə taʊɝ wʊdn bi dɪvaɪɾəd.

"Yes," Elaida mused, "if the sisters had been obedient, then the Tower wouldn't be divided.

ðoʊz ɹɛbəlz wʊɾə oʊbeɪd ɹæðɝ ðən ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf laɪk ə sɪli flɑk ə stɑɹɾəld bɝdz. ɪf ðə sɪstɝz wɝ oʊbiɾiənt, wi wəɾ əv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn əɹ hænz, ən ðoʊz hɔɹəd mɛn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ 'blæk taʊɝ' wʊɾə bɪn dɛlt wɪð lɔŋ əɡoʊ. wʌt dʒju θɪŋk, maɪdɑni?"

Those rebels would have obeyed rather than running off like a silly flock of startled birds. If the sisters were obedient, we would have the Dragon Reborn in our hands, and those horrid men training in their 'Black Tower' would have been dealt with long ago. What do you think, Meidani?"

"aɪ . . . oʊbiɾiəns ɪz sɝɾənli ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ɪleɪɾə."

"I . . . obedience is certainly important, Elaida."

ɪleɪɾə ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əz ɛɡwin leɪɾəld sup ɪndə hɝ boʊl. "ɛniwʌn wəɾ ədmɪt ðæt, maɪdɑni. aɪ æskt wʌt ʃəd bi dʌn. fɔɹtʃənətli, aɪ hæv ən aɪdiə maɪsɛlf. dʌzn ɪt stʃɹaɪk jə əz stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət ðə θɹi oʊðz kənteɪn noʊ mɛnʃən ʌv oʊbiɾiəns tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ? sɪstɝz kænɑt laɪ, kænɑt meɪk ə wɛpən fəɹ mɛn tə kɪl ʌðɝ mɛn, ən kænɑt juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən əɡɛnst ʌðɝz ɪksɛpt ɪn dɪfɛns. ðoʊz oʊðz əv ɔlweɪz sim tu læks tə mi. waɪ noʊ oʊθ tə oʊbeɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn?

Elaida shook her head as Egwene ladled soup into her bowl. "Anyone would admit that, Meidani. I asked what should be done. Fortunately, I have an idea myself. Doesn't it strike you as strange that the Three Oaths contain no mention of obedience to the White Tower? Sisters cannot lie, cannot make a weapon for men to kill other men, and cannot use the Power as a weapon against others except in defense. Those oaths have always seemed too lax to me. Why no oath to obey the Amyrlin?

ɪf ðət sɪmpəl pɹɑməs wɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɔl ʌv ʌs, haʊ mʌtʃ peɪn ən dɪfəkəlti kəd wɪv əvɔɪɾəd?

If that simple promise were part of all of us, how much pain and difficulty could we have avoided?

pɝhæps səm ɹivɪʒən ɪz ɪn ɔɹɾɝ."

Perhaps some revision is in order."

ɛɡwin stʊd stɪl. wʌns, ʃi hɝsɛlf hædn ʌndɝstʊd ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə ði oʊðz. ʃi səspɛktəd ðət mɛni ə nɑvəs ən æksɛptɪd hæd kwɛstʃən ðɛɹ jusfəlnəs. bʌt ʃi hæd lɝnd, əz ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌst, ðɛɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəns. ðə θɹi oʊðz wɝ wʌt meɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ wɝ wʌt kɛp ði ɛɛs sədaɪ duɪŋ wʌt wɑz bɛs fəɹ ðə wɝld, bʌt mɔɹ ðən ðæt, ðeɪ wɝ ə ʃɛltɝ fɹəm ækjəzeɪʃənz.

Egwene stood still. Once, she herself hadn't understood the importance of the oaths. She suspected that many a novice and Accepted had questioned their usefulness. But she had learned, as every Aes Sedai must, their importance. The Three Oaths were what made the Aes Sedai. They were what kept the Aes Sedai doing what was best for the world, but more than that, they were a shelter from accusations.

tʃeɪnʒɪŋ əm . . . wɛl, ɪt wəd bi ən ənpɹɛsɪdɛntɪd dɪzæstɝ. ɪleɪɾə ʃəd noʊ ðæt. ðə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn dʒʌs tɝn bæk tə hɝ sup, smaɪlɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, noʊ daʊt kɑntəmpleɪɾɪŋ ə fɔɹθ oʊθ tə dɪmæn oʊbiɾiəns. kʊdnt ʃi si haʊ ðət wəɾ ʌndɝmaɪn ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf? ɪt wəd tʃɹænsfɔɹm ði æmɪɝlɪn fɹəm ə liɾɝ tə ə dɛspət!

Changing them . . . well, it would be an unprecedented disaster. Elaida should know that. The false Amyrlin just turned back to her soup, smiling to herself, no doubt contemplating a fourth oath to demand obedience. Couldn't she see how that would undermine the Tower itself? It would transform the Amyrlin from a leader to a despot!

ɛɡwinz ɹeɪdʒ bɔɪld wɪðɪn hɝ, stimɪŋ laɪk ðə sup ɪn əɹ hænz. ðɪs wʊmən, ðɪs . . .

Egwene's rage boiled within her, steaming like the soup in her hands. This woman, this . . .

kɹitʃɝ! ʃi wɑz ðə kɑz ə ðə pɹɑbləmz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn u kɑz dɪvɪʒən bɪtwin ɹɛbəlz ən lɔɪəlɪsts. ʃi hæd teɪkən ɹænd kæptɪv ən biɾən hɪm. ʃi wɑz ə dɪzæstɝ!

creature! She was the cause of the problems in the White Tower, she was the one who caused division between rebels and loyalists. She had taken Rand captive and beaten him. She was a disaster!

ɛɡwin fɛl hɝsɛlf ʃeɪkɪŋ. ɪn ənʌðɝ moʊmənt, ʃid bɝst ən lɛɾ ɪleɪɾə hɪɹ tʃɹuθ. ɪt wɑz bɔɪlɪŋ fɹi fɹəm hɝ, ən ʃi kəd bɛɹli kənteɪn ɪt.

Egwene felt herself shaking. In another moment, she'd burst and let Elaida hear truth. It was boiling free from her, and she could barely contain it.

noʊ! ʃi θɔt. ɪf aɪ də ðæt, maɪ bæɾəl ɛnz. aɪ luz maɪ wɔɹ.

No! she thought. If I do that, my battle ends. I lose my war.

soʊ ɛɡwin dɪd ði oʊnli θɪŋ ʃi kəd θɪŋk ə tə stɑp hɝsɛlf. ʃi dʌmp ðə sup ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

So Egwene did the only thing she could think of to stop herself. She dumped the soup on the floor.

bɹaʊnɪʃ lɪkwəd spɹeɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə dɛləkət ɹʌɡ ʌv ɹɛd, jɛloʊ ən ɡɹin bɝdz əflaɪt. ɪleɪɾə kɝst, dʒʌmpɪŋ ʌp fɹəm əɹ siɾ ən bækɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə spɪl. nʌn ə ðə lɪkwəd hæd ɡɑɾən ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs, wɪtʃ wɑz ə ʃeɪm. ɛɡwin kɑmli snætʃt ə sɝvɪŋ taʊəl ɔf ə ðə teɪbəl ən bɪɡæn tə mɑp ʌp ðə spɪl.

Brownish liquid sprayed across the delicate rug of red, yellow and green birds aflight. Elaida cursed, jumping up from her seat and backing away from the spill. None of the liquid had gotten on her dress, which was a shame. Egwene calmly snatched a serving towel off of the table and began to mop up the spill.

"ju klʌmzi ɪɾiət!" ɪleɪɾə snæpt.

"You clumsy idiot!" Elaida snapped.

"aɪm sɑɹi," ɛɡwin sɛd, "aɪ wɪʃ ðət hædn hæpənd." ən ʃi dɪd. ʃi wɪʃt nʌn ə ðɪs ivnɪŋ hæɾ əkɝd. ʃi wɪʃt ɪleɪɾə wɝn ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl; ʃi wɪʃt ðə taʊɝ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn bɹoʊkən. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hædn bɪn fɔɹs tə spɪl ðə sup ɑn ðə flɔɹ. bʌt ʃi hæd. ən soʊ ʃi dɛlt wɪð ɪt, nilɪŋ ən skɹʌbɪŋ.

"I'm sorry," Egwene said, "I wish that hadn't happened." And she did. She wished none of this evening had occurred. She wished Elaida weren't in control; she wished the Tower had never been broken. She wished she hadn't been forced to spill the soup on the floor. But she had. And so she dealt with it, kneeling and scrubbing.

ɪleɪɾə spʌɾɝd, pɔɪntɪŋ. "ðæt ɹʌɡ ɪz wɝθ mɔɹ ðən jəɹ ɪntaɪɝ vɪlədʒ, waɪldɝ! maɪdɑni, hɛlp hɝ!"

Elaida sputtered, pointing. "That rug is worth more than your entire village, wilder! Meidani, help her!"

ðə ɡɹeɪ dɪdn ɔfɝ ə sɪŋɡəl əbdʒɛkʃən. ʃi skɝiɾ oʊvɝ ən ɡɹæbd ə bʌkəɾ ə tʃɪld wɔɾɝ, wɪtʃ hæd bɪn kulɪŋ səm waɪn, ən hɝid bæk tə hɛlp ɛɡwin. ɪleɪɾə muvd oʊvɝ tə ə dɔɹ ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum tə kɔl fəɹ sɝvəns.

The Gray didn't offer a single objection. She scurried over and grabbed a bucket of chilled water, which had been cooling some wine, and hurried back to help Egwene. Elaida moved over to a door on the far side of the room to call for servants.

"sɛn fəɹ mi," ɛɡwin wɪspɝɾ əz maɪdɑni nɛl daʊn tə hɛlp klin.

"Send for me," Egwene whispered as Meidani knelt down to help clean.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"sɛn fəɹ mi tə ɡɪmi ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən," ɛɡwin sɛd kwaɪətli, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪɾə, huz bæk wɑz tɝnd. "wi nid tə spik."

"Send for me to give me instruction," Egwene said quietly, glancing at Elaida, whose back was turned. "We need to speak."

ɛɡwin hæɾ ɝɪdʒənəli ɪntɛndəd tə əvɔɪd ðə sɑlədɑɹ spaɪz, lɛɾɪŋ bioʊnɪn ækt əz əɹ mɛsənʒɝ.

Egwene had originally intended to avoid the Salidar spies, letting Beonin act as her messenger.

bʌt ʃi hæd tu mɛni kwɛstʃənz. waɪ hædn maɪdɑni flɛd ðə taʊɝ? wʌt wɝ ðə spaɪz plænɪŋ?

But she had too many questions. Why hadn't Meidani fled the Tower? What were the spies planning?

hæɾ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz bɪn ədɑptəd baɪ ɪleɪɾə ən biɾən daʊn əz saʊnli əz maɪdɑni?

Had any of the others been adopted by Elaida and beaten down as soundly as Meidani?

maɪdɑni ɡlænst əɾ ɪleɪɾə, ðən bæk əɾ ɛɡwin. "aɪ meɪ nɑt sim ɪt səmtaɪmz, bʌɾ aɪm stɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɡɝl. jə kænɑɾ ɔɹɾɝ mi."

Meidani glanced at Elaida, then back at Egwene. "I may not seem it sometimes, but I'm still Aes Sedai, girl. You cannot order me."

"aɪ æm jəɹ æmɪɝlɪn, maɪdɑni," ɛɡwin sɛd kɑmli, ɹɪŋɪŋ ə taʊɛlfəl ə sup ɪndə ə pɪtʃɝ.

"I am your Amyrlin, Meidani," Egwene said calmly, wringing a towelful of soup into a pitcher.

"æn jə wəd də bɛs tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt. ənlɛs jə wɑn ðə θɹi oʊðz ɹipleɪst wɪð vaʊz tə sɝv ɪleɪɾə fəɹ ɪtɝnəɾi."

"And you would do best to remember it. Unless you want the Three Oaths replaced with vows to serve Elaida for eternity."

maɪdɑni ɡlænst ət hɝ, ðən kɹɪnʒd əɾ ɪleɪɾəz ʃɹɪl kɔlz fəɹ sɝvəns. ðə pʊɹ wʊmən hæɾ ɑbviəsli sin ə hɑɹd taɪm leɪtli.

Meidani glanced at her, then cringed at Elaida's shrill calls for servants. The poor woman had obviously seen a hard time lately.

ɛɡwin leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "ɪleɪɾə kən bi ənsiɾɪd, maɪdɑni. ðə taʊɝ wɪl bi ɹiunaɪɾɪd. əl si ɪt hæpən, bʌt wi mʌs kip kɝədʒ. sɛn fəɹ mi."

Egwene laid a hand on her shoulder. "Elaida can be unseated, Meidani. The Tower will be reunited. I will see it happen, but we must keep courage. Send for me."

maɪdɑni lʊkt ʌp, stʌɾiɪŋ ɛɡwin. "haʊ . . . haʊ dʒju də ɪt? ðeɪ seɪ jə ɑɹ pʌnɪʃt θɹi ən fɔɹ taɪmz ə deɪ, ðət jə nid hilɪŋ bɪtwin soʊ ðət ðeɪ kən bit jə fɝðɝ. haʊ kən jə teɪk ɪt?"

Meidani looked up, studying Egwene. "How . . . how do you do it? They say you are punished three and four times a day, that you need Healing between so that they can beat you further. How can you take it?"

"aɪ teɪk ɪt kəz aɪ mʌst," ɛɡwin sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ əɹ hænd. "dʒʌst əz wi ɔl də wʌt wi mʌst.

"I take it because I must," Egwene said, lowering her hand. "Just as we all do what we must.

jəɹ sɝvəs hɪɹ wɑtʃɪŋ ɪleɪɾə ɪz dɪfəkəlt, aɪ kən si, bʌt noʊ ðət jəɹ wɝk ɪz noʊɾəst ən əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd."

Your service here watching Elaida is difficult, I can see, but know that your work is noticed and appreciated."

ɛɡwin dɪdnt noʊ ɪf maɪdɑni ɹɪli hæd bɪn sɛn tə spaɪ ɑn ɪleɪɾə, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz bɛɾɝ fəɹ ə wʊmən tə θɪŋk ðəɾ əɹ sʌfɝɪŋ wɑz fəɹ ə ɡʊd pɝpəs. ɪt sim tə hæv bɪn ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə seɪ, fəɹ maɪdɑni stʃɹeɪɾənd, teɪkɪŋ hɑɹɾ ən nɑɾɪŋ. "θæŋk ju."

Egwene didn't know if Meidani really had been sent to spy on Elaida, but it was always better for a woman to think that her suffering was for a good purpose. It seemed to have been the right thing to say, for Meidani straightened, taking heart and nodding. "Thank you."

ɪleɪɾə wɑz ɹɪtɝnɪŋ, bɪhaɪn əɹ θɹi sɝvəns.

Elaida was returning, behind her three servants.

"sɛn fəɹ mi," ɛɡwin ɔɹɾɝd maɪdɑni əɡɛn, vɔɪs ə wɪspɝ. "aɪ æm wʌn ə ðə fju ɪn ðɪs taʊɝ u hæz ə ɡʊɾ ɪkskjus tə muv bɪtwin ðə vɛɹiəs ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝz. aɪ kən hɛlp hil wʌɾ əz bɪn bɹoʊkən, bʌɾ əl nid jəɹ hɛlp."

"Send for me," Egwene ordered Meidani again, voice a whisper. "I am one of the few in this Tower who has a good excuse to move between the various Ajah quarters. I can help heal what has been broken, but I will need your help."

maɪdɑni hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd. "vɛɹi wɛl."

Meidani hesitated, then nodded. "Very well."

"ju!" ɪleɪɾə snæpt, stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə ɛɡwin. "aʊt! aɪ wɑn jə tə tɛl sɪlviænə tə stʃɹæp jə əz ʃiz nɛvɝ stʃɹæpt ə wʊmən bɪfɔɹ! aɪ wɑn əɹ tə pʌnɪʃ ju, ðən hil jə ɑn ðə spɑt, ðən bit jə əɡɛn! ɡoʊ!"

"You!" Elaida snapped, stepping up to Egwene. "Out! I want you to tell Silviana to strap you as she's never strapped a woman before! I want her to punish you, then Heal you on the spot, then beat you again! Go!"

ɛɡwin stʊd, hændɪŋ əɹ taʊəl tə wʌn ə ðə sɝvəns. ðən ʃi wɔk tə ði ɛɡzɪt.

Egwene stood, handing her towel to one of the servants. Then she walked to the exit.

"æn doʊn θɪŋk ðət jəɹ klʌmzinəs əz əlaʊd jə tə ɪskeɪp jəɹ duɾiz," ɪleɪɾə kəntɪnjud fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. "ju wɪl ɹɪtɝn ən sɝv mi əɡɛn ɑn ənʌðɝ deɪt. ən ɪf jə soʊ mʌtʃ əz spɪl ənʌðɝ dʒɹɑp, əl əv jə lɑkt əweɪ ɪn ə sɛl wɪð noʊ wɪndoʊz əɹ laɪts fəɹ ə wik. dʒju ʌndɝstænd?"

"And don't think that your clumsiness has allowed you to escape your duties," Elaida continued from behind. "You will return and serve me again on another date. And if you so much as spill another drop, I will have you locked away in a cell with no windows or lights for a week. Do you understand?"

ɛɡwin lɛf ðə ɹum. hæd ðɪs wʊmən ɛvɝ bɪn ə tʃɹu ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝ ɪmoʊʃənz?

Egwene left the room. Had this woman ever been a true Aes Sedai, in control of her emotions?

jɛɾ ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf hæd lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝ ɪmoʊʃənz. ʃi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛt hɝsɛlf ɡɛt tə ə pɔɪnt wɛɹ ʃid bɪn fɔɹs tə dʒɹɑp ðə sup. ʃi hæɾ ʌndɝɛstəmeɪɾɪd haʊ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ ɪleɪɾə kəd bi, bʌt ðət wəd nɑt hæpən əɡɛn. ʃi kɑm hɝsɛlf əz ʃi wɔkt, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊt. ɹeɪdʒ dɪɾ əɹ noʊ ɡʊd. jə dɪdnt ɡɛt mæɾ ət ðə wizəl u wɑz snikɪŋ ɪndə jəɹ jɑɹɾ ən iɾɪŋ jəɹ hɛnz.

Yet Egwene herself had lost control of her emotions. She should never have let herself get to a point where she'd been forced to drop the soup. She had underestimated how infuriating Elaida could be, but that would not happen again. She calmed herself as she walked, breathing in and out. Rage did her no good. You didn't get mad at the weasel who was sneaking into your yard and eating your hens.

jə sɪmpli leɪɾ ə tʃɹæp ən dɪspoʊzd ə ði ænəməl. æŋɡɝ wɑz pɔɪnləs.

You simply laid a trap and disposed of the animal. Anger was pointless.

hænz stɪl smɛlɪŋ feɪnli ʌv pɛpɝ ən spaɪsəz, ʃi meɪɾ əɹ weɪ daʊn tə ðə loʊəs lɛvəl ə ðə taʊɝ, tə ðə nɑvəsɪz' daɪnɪŋ hɔl bɪsaɪd ðə meɪn kɪtʃənz. ɛɡwin hæd wɝkt ɪn ðoʊz kɪtʃənz hɝsɛlf fɹikwənli dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs naɪn deɪz; ɛvɹi nɑvəs wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə wɝk tʃɔɹz. ðə smɛlz ə ðə pleɪs - tʃɑɹkoʊl ən smoʊk, sɪmɝɪŋ sups ən ʃɑɹp, ənsɛntɪd soʊps - wɝ vɛɹi fəmɪljɝ tə hɝ. ðə smɛlz wɝn ðət dɪfɹənt, æktʃəli , fɹəm ðə kɪtʃən ə hɝ fɑðɝz ɪn bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

Hands still smelling faintly of pepper and spices, she made her way down to the lowest level of the Tower, to the novices' dining hall beside the main kitchens. Egwene had worked in those kitchens herself frequently during the last nine days; every novice was required to work chores. The smells of the place - charcoal and smoke, simmering soups and sharp, unscented soaps - were very familiar to her. The smells weren't that different, actually, from the kitchen of her father's inn back in the Two Rivers.

ðə waɪt-wɔld ɹum wɑz ɛmpti, ðə teɪbəlz sɪɾɪŋ ənətɛndɪd, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz ə smɔl tʃɹeɪ ɑn wʌn ə ðɛm, kʌvɝd wɪð ə pɑt lɪd tə kip ɪt wɔɹm. hɝ kʊʃən wɑz ðəɹ əz wɛl, lɛf baɪ ðə nɑvəsɪz tə sɑfən ðə hɑɹd bɛntʃ. ɛɡwin əpɹoʊtʃt, bʌɾ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə kʊʃən əz ʃi ɔlweɪz dɪd, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ðə dʒɛstʃɝ. ʃi sæɾ ən ɹimuv ðə lɪd fɹəm ðə mil. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ɔl ʃi faʊnd wɑz ə boʊl ə ðə seɪm bɹaʊnɪʃ sup. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɪn ə ðə ɹoʊst, ɡɹeɪvi əɹ lɔŋ, θɪn bʌɾɝd binz ðət hæd meɪɾ ʌp ðə ɹɛst ʌv ɪleɪɾəz mil.

The white-walled room was empty, the tables sitting unattended, though there was a small tray on one of them, covered with a pot lid to keep it warm. Her cushion was there as well, left by the novices to soften the hard bench. Egwene approached, but ignored the cushion as she always did, though she was grateful for the gesture. She sat and removed the lid from the meal. Unfortunately, all she found was a bowl of the same brownish soup. There was no hint of the roast, gravy or long, thin buttered beans that had made up the rest of Elaida's meal.

stɪl, ɪt wɑz fud, ən ɛɡwinz stʌmək wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ɪt. ɪleɪɾə hædn ɔɹɾɝd ðət ʃi ɪmiɾiətli ɡoʊ fəɹ pʌnɪʃmənt, ən soʊ sɪlviænəz ɔɹɾɝ ðət ʃi it fɝs tʊk pɹɛsəɾəns. ɔɹ, ət list, ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf ʌv ən ɑɹɡjəmən ðəɹ tə pɹətɛk hɝ.

Still, it was food, and Egwene's stomach was grateful for it. Elaida hadn't ordered that she immediately go for punishment, and so Silviana's order that she eat first took precedence. Or, at least, there was enough of an argument there to protect her.

ʃi eɪt kwaɪətli, əloʊn. ðə sup wɑz ɪndid spaɪsi, ən ɪt teɪstəɾ əz mʌtʃ ə pɛpɝ əz ɪt hæd smɛld, bʌt ʃi dɪdn maɪnd. ʌðɝ ðən ðæt, ɪt wɑz æktʃəli  kwaɪt ɡʊd. ʃiɾ ɔlsoʊ bɪn lɛft ə fju slaɪsəz ə bɹɛd, ðoʊ ʃid ɡɑɾən ði ɛnz ə ðə loʊf. ɔl ɪn ɔl, nɑɾ ə bæd mil fəɹ sʌmwʌn u hæd θɔt ʃi maɪt ɡɛt nʌθɪŋ.

She ate quietly, alone. The soup was indeed spicy, and it tasted as much of pepper as it had smelled, but she didn't mind. Other than that, it was actually quite good. She'd also been left a few slices of bread, though she'd gotten the ends of the loaf. All in all, not a bad meal for someone who had thought she might get nothing.

ɛɡwin eɪt kəntəmpləɾɪvli, lɪsnɪŋ tə lɑɹəz ən ðə skʌljənz bæŋ pɑts ət wɑʃɪŋ ʌp ɪn ði ʌðɝ ɹum, sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ kɑm ʃi fɛlt. ʃi hæd tʃeɪnʒd; sʌmθɪŋ wɑz dɪfɹən əbaʊt hɝ.

Egwene ate contemplatively, listening to Laras and the scullions bang pots at washing up in the other room, surprised at how calm she felt. She had changed; something was different about her.

wɑtʃɪŋ ɪleɪɾə, faɪnəli kənfɹʌntɪŋ ðə wʊmən u hæd bɪn əɹ ɹaɪvəl ɔl ə ðiz mʌnθs, fɔɹst əɹ tə lʊk ət wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ɪn ə nu laɪt.

Watching Elaida, finally confronting the woman who had been her rival all of these months, forced her to look at what she was doing in a new light.

ʃi hæɾ ɪmædʒən hɝsɛlf ʌndɝmaɪnɪŋ ɪleɪɾə ən sizɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ fɹəm wɪðɪn.

She had imagined herself undermining Elaida and seizing control of the White Tower from within.

naʊ ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi dɪdnt nid tə ʌndɝmaɪn ɪleɪɾə. ðə wʊmən wɑz fʊli keɪpəbəl ə duɪŋ ðət hɝsɛlf. waɪ, ɛɡwin kəd pɪktʃɝ ðə ɹiækʃən ə ðə sɪɾɝz ən ədʒɑ hɛdz wən ɪleɪɾə ənaʊnst əɹ ɪntɛntʃən tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə θɹi oʊðz!

Now she realized that she didn't need to undermine Elaida. The woman was fully capable of doing that herself. Why, Egwene could picture the reaction of the Sitters and Ajah heads when Elaida announced her intention to change the Three Oaths!

ɪleɪɾə wəd tɑpəl ɪvɛntʃəwəli, wɪð əɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɛɡwinz hɛlp. ɛɡwinz duɾi, əz æmɪɝlɪn, wɑzn tə spid ðət fɔl - bʌt tə də wʌtɛvɝ ʃi kəd tə hoʊl ðə taʊɝ ən ɪts ɑkjəpəns təɡɛðɝ.

Elaida would topple eventually, with or without Egwene's help. Egwene's duty, as Amyrlin, wasn't to speed that fall - but to do whatever she could to hold the Tower and its occupants together.

ðeɪ kʊdn əfɔɹd tə fɹæktʃɝ fɝðɝ. hɝ duɾi wɑz tə hoʊl bæk ðə keɪɑs ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ðət θɹɛɾənd əm ɔl, tə ɹɪfɔɝdʒ ðə taʊɝ. əz ʃi fɪnɪʃt ɔf əɹ sup, juzɪŋ ðə læs pis ə bɹɛd tə waɪp ðə ɹɛmnəns fɹəm ðə boʊl, ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæd tə də wʌtɛvɝ ʃi kəd tə bi ə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ. taɪm wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ vɛɹi ʃɔɹt. wʌt wɑz ɹænd duɪŋ tə ðə wɝld wɪθaʊt ɡaɪɾəns? wən wəd ðə sintʃæn ətæk tə ðə nɔɹθ? ðeɪɾ əv tə kʌt θɹu ændɝ tə ɡɛt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən wʌt dɪstʃɹʌkʃən wəd ðət kɑz? ʃʊɹli ʃi hæd səm taɪm tə ɹɪfɔɝdʒ ðə taʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ði ətæk keɪm, bʌt noʊ moʊməns tə weɪst.

They couldn't afford to fracture further. Her duty was to hold back the chaos and destruction that threatened them all, to reforge the Tower. As she finished off her soup, using the last piece of bread to wipe the remnants from the bowl, she realized she had to do whatever she could to be a strength to the sisters in the Tower. Time was growing very short. What was Rand doing to the world without guidance? When would the Seanchan attack to the north? They'd have to cut through Andor to get to Tar Valon, and what destruction would that cause? Surely she had some time to reforge the Tower before the attack came, but no moments to waste.

ɛɡwin tʊk əɹ dɪʃ ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən pɹɑpɝ ən wɑʃt ɪt hɝsɛlf, ɝnɪŋ ə nɑɾ ʌv əpɹuvəl fɹəm ðə hɛfti mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə kɪtʃənz. æftɝ ðæt, ɛɡwin meɪɾ əɹ weɪ ʌp tə sɪlviænəz stʌɾi. ʃi niɾəd tə ɡɛɾ əɹ pʌnɪʃmən dʌn kwɪkli; ʃi stɪl ɪntɛndəd tə vɪzət lin tənaɪt, əz wɑz əɹ kʌstəm. ɛɡwin nɑkt, ðən ɛntɝd, faɪndɪŋ sɪlviænə əɾ əɹ dɛsk, lifɪŋ θɹu ə θɪk toʊm baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə tu sɪlvɝ læmps. wən ɛɡwin ɛntɝd, sɪlviænə mɑɹk ðə peɪdʒ wɪð ə smɔl lɛŋθ ə ɹɛd klɔθ, ðən ʃʌɾ ɪt. ðə wɔɹn kʌvɝ ɹɛd mɛɾɪteɪʃənz ɑn ðə kɪnlɪŋ fleɪm, ə hɪstɝi ʌv ðə ɹaɪz ə vɛɹiəs æmɪɝlənz. kjʊɹiəs.

Egwene took her dish into the kitchen proper and washed it herself, earning a nod of approval from the hefty Mistress of the Kitchens. After that, Egwene made her way up to Silviana's study. She needed to get her punishment done quickly; she still intended to visit Leane tonight, as was her custom. Egwene knocked, then entered, finding Silviana at her desk, leafing through a thick tome by the light of two silver lamps. When Egwene entered, Silviana marked the page with a small length of red cloth, then shut it. The worn cover read Meditations on the Kindling Flame, a history of the rise of various Amyrlins. Curious.

ɛɡwin sæt daʊn ɑn ə stul bɪfɔɹ ðə dɛsk - nɑt flɪntʃɪŋ ət ði ɪmiɾiət ʃɑɹp peɪn ə hɝ bæksaɪd - ən spoʊk kɑmli əbaʊt ði ivnɪŋ, oʊmɪɾɪŋ ðə fæk ðət ʃid dʒɹɑp ðə boʊl ə sup ɑn pɝpəs. ʃi dɪd, haʊɛvɝ, seɪ ðət ʃid dʒɹɑpt ɪɾ æftɝ ɪleɪɾə hæd tɔkt ə ɹɪvoʊkɪŋ ən tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ðə θɹi oʊðz.

Egwene sat down on a stool before the desk - not flinching at the immediate sharp pain of her backside - and spoke calmly about the evening, omitting the fact that she'd dropped the bowl of soup on purpose. She did, however, say that she'd dropped it after Elaida had talked of revoking and changing the Three Oaths.

sɪlviænə lʊk vɛɹi θɔtfəl ət ðæt.

Silviana looked very thoughtful at that.

"wɛl," ðə wʊmən sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp ən fɛtʃɪŋ əɹ læʃ, "ði æmɪɝlɪn əz spoʊkən."

"Well," the woman said, standing up and fetching her lash, "the Amyrlin has spoken."

"jɛs, aɪ hæv," ɛɡwin sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp ən pəzɪʃənɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə teɪbəl, skɝts ən ʃɪft ʌp fəɹ ðə biɾɪŋ.

"Yes, I have," Egwene said, standing up and positioning herself on the table, skirts and shift up for the beating.

sɪlviænə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən ðən ðə stʃɹæpɪŋ bɪɡæn. ɑdli, ɛɡwin fɛl noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə kɹaɪ aʊt. ɪt hɝt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ʃi dʒʌs kʊdn skɹim. haʊ ɹɪdɪkjələs ðə pʌnɪʃmənt wɑz!

Silviana hesitated, and then the strapping began. Oddly, Egwene felt no desire to cry out. It hurt, of course, but she just couldn't scream. How ridiculous the punishment was!

ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ peɪn ət siɪŋ ðə sɪstɝz pæs ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð fɪɹ, səspɪʃən ən dɪstʃɹʌst. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ði æɡəni ʌv sɝvɪŋ ɪleɪɾə waɪl hoʊldɪŋ əɹ tʌŋ.

She remembered her pain at seeing the sisters pass in the hallways, regarding one another with fear, suspicion and distrust. She remembered the agony of serving Elaida while holding her tongue.

ən ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə ʃɪɹ hɔɹɝ ət ði aɪdiə ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə taʊɝ biɪŋ baʊn baɪ oʊθ tə oʊbeɪ sətʃ ə taɪɹənt.

And she remembered the sheer horror at the idea of everyone in the Tower being bound by oath to obey such a tyrant.

ɛɡwin ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ pɪɾi fəɹ pʊɹ maɪdɑni. noʊ sɪstɝ ʃəd bi tʃɹiɾəd ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ.

Egwene remembered her pity for poor Meidani. No sister should be treated in such a way.

ɪmpɹɪzənmənt wɑz wʌn θɪŋ. bʌt biɾɪŋ ə wʊmən daʊn, tɔɪɪŋ wɪð hɝ, hɪntɪŋ ət ðə tɔɹtʃɝ tə kʌm? ɪt wɑz ɪnsʌfɝəbəl.

Imprisonment was one thing. But beating a woman down, toying with her, hinting at the torture to come? It was insufferable.

itʃ ə ðiz θɪŋz wɑz ə peɪn ɪnsaɪɾ ʌv ɛɡwin, ə naɪf tə ðə tʃɛst, pɪɹsɪŋ ðə hɑɹt. əz ðə biɾɪŋ kəntɪnjud, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət nʌθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd də tə hɝ bɑɾi wəɾ ɛvɝ kəmpɛɹ tə ðə peɪn ə soʊl ʃi fɛlt ət siɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ sʌfɝ bɪniθ ɪleɪɾəz hænd. kəmpɛɹd wɪð ðoʊz ɪntɝnəl æɡəniz, ðə biɾɪŋ wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs.

Each of these things was a pain inside of Egwene, a knife to the chest, piercing the heart. As the beating continued, she realized that nothing they could do to her body would ever compare to the pain of soul she felt at seeing the White Tower suffer beneath Elaida's hand. Compared with those internal agonies, the beating was ridiculous.

ən soʊ ʃi bɪɡæn tə læf.

And so she began to laugh.

ɪt wɑzn ə fɔɹs læf. ɪt wɑzn ə dɪfaɪən læf. ɪt wɑz ðə læftɝ ə dɪsbɪlif. ʌv ɪnkɹədulɪɾi.

It wasn't a forced laugh. It wasn't a defiant laugh. It was the laughter of disbelief. Of incredulity.

haʊ kəd ðeɪ θɪŋk ðət biɾɪŋ əɹ wəd sɑlv ɛniθɪŋ? ɪt wɑz luɾəkɹəs!

How could they think that beating her would solve anything? It was ludicrous!

ðə læʃɪŋ stɑpt. ɛɡwin tɝnd. ʃʊɹli ðət wɑzn ɔl ʌv ɪt!

The lashing stopped. Egwene turned. Surely that wasn't all of it!

sɪlviænə wɑz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ əɹ wɪð ə kənsɝn ɪkspɹɛʃən. "tʃaɪld?" ʃi æskt. "ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?"

Silviana was regarding her with a concerned expression. "Child?" she asked. "Are you all right?"

"aɪ æm kwaɪt wɛl."

"I am quite well."

"ju . . . ɑɹ sɝɾən? haʊ ɑɹ jəɹ θɔts?"

"You . . . are certain? How are your thoughts?"

ʃi θɪŋks aɪv bɹoʊkən ʌndɝ ðə stʃɹeɪn, ɛɡwin ɹilaɪzd. ʃi bits mi ən aɪ læf fɹəm ɪt.

She thinks I've broken under the strain, Egwene realized. She beats me and I laugh from it.

"maɪ θɔts ɑɹ wɛl," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ doʊn læf kəz aɪv bɪn bɹoʊkən, sɪlviænə. aɪ læf kəz ɪts əbsɝd tə bit mi."

"My thoughts are well," Egwene said. "I don't laugh because I've been broken, Silviana. I laugh because it is absurd to beat me."

ðə wʊmənz ɪkspɹɛʃən dɑɹkənd.

The woman's expression darkened.

"kæn jə si ɪt?" ɛɡwin æskt. "doʊn jə fil ðə peɪn? ði æɡəni ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ ðə taʊɝ kɹʌmbəl ɝaʊn ju? kəɾ ɛni biɾɪŋ kəmpɛɹ tə ðæt?"

"Can't you see it?" Egwene asked. "Don't you feel the pain? The agony of watching the Tower crumble around you? Could any beating compare to that?"

sɪlviænə dɪd nɑt ɹɪspɑnd.

Silviana did not respond.

aɪ ʌndɝstænd, ɛɡwin θɔt. aɪ dɪdn ɹilaɪz wʌt ði il dɪd. aɪ əsum ðəɾ aɪ dʒʌs hæd tə bi hɑɹɾɝ, ən ðət wɑz wʌt wəd titʃ mi tə læf ət peɪn. bʌɾ ɪts nɑt hɑɹdnəs əɾ ɔl. ɪts nɑt stʃɹɛŋkθ ðət meɪks mi læf. ɪts ʌndɝstændɪŋ.

I understand, Egwene thought. I didn't realize what the Aiel did. I assumed that I just had to be harder, and that was what would teach me to laugh at pain. But it's not hardness at all. It's not strength that makes me laugh. It's understanding.

tə lɛt ðə taʊɝ fɔl, tə lɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪl - ðə peɪn ə ðət wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɝ. ʃi hæd tə stɑp ɪt, fəɹ ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

To let the Tower fall, to let the Aes Sedai fail - the pain of that would destroy her. She had to stop it, for she was the Amyrlin Seat.

"aɪ kænɑt ɹəfjuz tə pʌnɪʃ ju," sɪlviænə sɛd. "ju ɹilaɪz ðæt."

"I cannot refuse to punish you," Silviana said. "You realize that."

"ʌv kɔɹs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌt pliz ɹimaɪn mi ʌv sʌmθɪŋ. wʌt wɑz ɪt jə sɛɾ əbaʊt ʃimɹɪn? waɪ wɑz ɪɾ ɪleɪɾə ɡɑɾ əweɪ wɪð teɪkɪŋ ðə ʃɔl fɹəm hɝ?"

"Of course," Egwene said. "But please remind me of something. What was it you said about Shemerin? Why was it Elaida got away with taking the shawl from her?"

"ɪt wɑz kəz ʃimɹɪn æksɛptɪɾ ɪt," sɪlviænə ɹɪplaɪd. "ʃi tʃɹiɾəd hɝsɛlf əz ɪf ʃi ɹɪli hæd lɔs ðə ʃɔl. ʃi dɪdn faɪt bæk."

"It was because Shemerin accepted it," Silviana replied. "She treated herself as if she really had lost the shawl. She didn't fight back."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt meɪk ðə seɪm mɪsteɪk, sɪlviænə. ɪleɪɾə kən seɪ wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑns. bʌt ðət dʌzn tʃeɪnʒ u aɪ æm, əɹ u ɛni ʌv əs ɑɹ. ivən ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪz tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə θɹi oʊðz, ðəɹ wɪl bi ðoʊz u ɹɪzɪst, hu hoʊl tə wʌɾ ɪz kɝɛkt. ən soʊ, wən jə bit mi, jə bit ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

"I will not make the same mistake, Silviana. Elaida can say whatever she wants. But that doesn't change who I am, or who any of us are. Even if she tries to change the Three Oaths, there will be those who resist, who hold to what is correct. And so, when you beat me, you beat the Amyrlin Seat.

ən ðət ʃəd bi əmjuzɪŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk əs boʊθ læf."

And that should be amusing enough to make us both laugh."

ðə pʌnɪʃmən kəntɪnjud, ən ɛɡwin ɛmbɹeɪs ðə peɪn, tʊk ɪɾ ɪndə hɝsɛlf, ən dʒʌdʒd ɪɾ ɪnsɪɡnjɪfɪkənt, ɪmpeɪʃən fəɹ ðə pʌnɪʃmən tə sis.

The punishment continued, and Egwene embraced the pain, took it into herself, and judged it insignificant, impatient for the punishment to cease.

ʃi hæɾ ə lɑɾ ʌv wɝk tə du.

She had a lot of work to do.

tʃæptɝ θɹi

CHAPTER 3

ðə weɪz ʌv ɑnɝ eɪvinhə kɹaʊtʃt wɪð əɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz ən səm tʃɹu blʌd skaʊts ətɑp ðə loʊ, ɡɹæsi hɪl, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz. ðeɪ wɝ ə sɑɹi lɑt, ðiz dəmɑni wɛtləndɝz, wɪð dɝɾid feɪsəz ðət hæd nɑt sin ə swɛt tɛn ɪn mʌnθs, ðɛɹ ɪmeɪʃieɪɾɪd tʃɪlʒɹən tu hʌŋɡɹi tə kɹaɪ. wʌn sæd mjul pʊld ə sɪŋɡəl kɑɹɾ əmʌŋ ðə hʌnʒɹəd stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ pipəl; wʌt ðeɪ hædn paɪld ɪn ðə vihɪkəl ðeɪ kæɹid.

The Ways of Honor Aviendha crouched with her spear-sisters and some True Blood scouts atop the low, grassy hill, looking down at the refugees. They were a sorry lot, these Domani wetlanders, with dirtied faces that had not seen a sweat tent in months, their emaciated children too hungry to cry. One sad mule pulled a single cart among the hundred struggling people; what they hadn't piled in the vehicle they carried.

ðəɹ wɑzn mʌtʃ ʌv iðɝ. ðeɪ plɑɾəd nɔɹθist əlɔŋ ə pæθweɪ ðət kʊdn kwaɪt bi kɔld ə ɹoʊd. pɝhæps ðəɹ wɑz ə vɪlədʒ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən. pɝhæps ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs fliɪŋ ði ənsɝɾənti ʌv ðə koʊstəl lænz.

There wasn't much of either. They plodded northeast along a pathway that couldn't quite be called a road. Perhaps there was a village in that direction. Perhaps they were just fleeing the uncertainty of the coastal lands.

ðə hɪli lændskeɪp wɑz oʊpən seɪv fəɹ ði əkeɪʒənəl stæn ə tʃɹiz. ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz hædn sin eɪvinhə ən əɹ kəmpænjənz, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ wɝ lɛs ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əweɪ. ʃid nɛvɝ ʌndɝstʊd haʊ wɛtləndɝz kəd bi soʊ blaɪnd. dɪdn ðeɪ wɑtʃ, noʊɾɪŋ ɛni ɑɾətiz ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən? kʊdn ðeɪ si ðət tʃɹævlɪŋ soʊ nɪɹ tə ə hɪltɑp pɹæktəkli ɪnvaɪɾəd skaʊts tə spaɪ ɑn ðɛm?

The hilly landscape was open save for the occasional stand of trees. The refugees hadn't seen Aviendha and her companions, despite the fact that they were less than a hundred paces away. She'd never understood how wetlanders could be so blind. Didn't they watch, noting any oddities on the horizon? Couldn't they see that traveling so near to a hilltop practically invited scouts to spy on them?

ðeɪ ʃʊɾə sɪkjʊɹd ðə hɪl wɪð ðɛɹ oʊn skaʊts bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ.

They should have secured the hill with their own scouts before coming anywhere near.

dɪdn ðeɪ kɛɹ? eɪvinhə ʃɪvɝd. haʊ kəd jə nɑt kɛɹ əbaʊɾ aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ ju, aɪz ðət maɪt bɪlɔŋ tə ə mæn əɹ meɪɾən hoʊldɪŋ ə spɪɹ? wɝ ðeɪ soʊ iɡɝ tə weɪk fɹəm ðə dʒɹim?

Didn't they care? Aviendha shivered. How could you not care about eyes watching you, eyes that might belong to a man or Maiden holding a spear? Were they so eager to wake from the dream?

eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt fɪɹ dɛθ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə vɛɹi bɪɡ dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ dɛθ ən wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪt.

Aviendha did not fear death, but there was a very big difference between embracing death and wishing for it.

sɪɾiz, ʃi θɔt, ðəɹ ðə pɹɑbləm. sɪɾiz wɝ stɪŋkɪŋ, fɛstɝɪŋ pleɪsəz, laɪk sɔɹz ðət nɛvɝ hild. səm wɝ bɛɾɝ ðən ʌðɝz - ɪleɪn dɪɾ ən ædmɝəbəl dʒɑb wɪð keɪɛmlɪn - bʌt ðə bɛst ə ðɛm ɡæðɝd tu mɛni pipəl ən tɔɾ əm tə ɡɹoʊ kʌmftəɹbəl steɪɪŋ ɪn wʌn pleɪs. ɪf ðoʊz ɹɛfjudʒiz hæd bɪn əkʌstəm tə tʃɹævəl ən hæd lɝn tə juz ðɛɹ oʊn fit, ɹæðɝ ðən ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn hɔɹsəz əz wɛtləndɝz soʊ ɔfən dɪd, ðən ɪt wəd nɑt bi soʊ dɪfəkəl fəɹ əm tə liv ðɛɹ taʊnz.

Cities, she thought, they're the problem. Cities were stinking, festering places, like sores that never healed. Some were better than others - Elayne did an admirable job with Caemlyn - but the best of them gathered too many people and taught them to grow comfortable staying in one place. If those refugees had been accustomed to travel and had learned to use their own feet, rather than relying on horses as wetlanders so often did, then it would not be so difficult for them to leave their towns.

əmʌŋ ði il, ðə kɹæfsmən wɝ tʃɹeɪn tə dɪfɛn ðɛmsɛlvz, ðə tʃɪlʒɹən kəd lɪv ɔf ðə læn fəɹ deɪz, ən ivən blæksmɪθs kəd tʃɹævəl ɡɹeɪt dɪstənsəz kwɪkli. ən ɪntaɪɝ sɛp kəd bi ɑn ðə muv wɪðɪn ən aʊɝ, kæɹiɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ niɾəd ɑn ðɛɹ bæks.

Among the Aiel, the craftsmen were trained to defend themselves, the children could live off the land for days, and even blacksmiths could travel great distances quickly. An entire sept could be on the move within an hour, carrying everything they needed on their backs.

wɛtləndɝz wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ, daʊtləs. stɪl, ʃi fɛl pɪɾi fəɹ ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz. ði ɪmoʊʃən sɝpɹaɪz hɝ. waɪl ʃi wɑz nɑt hɑɹtləs, hɝ duɾi leɪ ɛlswɛɹ, wɪð ɹænd ælθɹ. ʃi hæd noʊ ɹizən tə fil hɑɹtsɔɹ fəɹ ə ɡɹup ʌv wɛtləndɝz ʃid nɛvɝ mɛt. bʌt taɪm spɛnt wɪð əɹ fɝst-sɪstɝ, ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, hæd tɔɾ əɹ ðət nɑɾ ɔl wɛtləndɝz wɝ sɑft ən wik. dʒʌs moʊst ə ðɛm. ðəɹ wɑz dʒi ɪn kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðoʊz u kəd nɑt kɛɹ fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz.

Wetlanders were strange, doubtless. Still, she felt pity for the refugees. The emotion surprised her. While she was not heartless, her duty lay elsewhere, with Rand al'Thor. She had no reason to feel heartsore for a group of wetlanders she'd never met. But time spent with her first-sister, Elayne Trakand, had taught her that not all wetlanders were soft and weak. Just most of them. There was ji in caring for those who could not care for themselves.

wɑtʃɪŋ ðiz ɹɛfjudʒiz, eɪvinhə tʃɹaɪd tə si ðɛm əz ɪleɪn wʊd, bʌt ʃi stɪl stʃɹʌɡəl tə ʌndɝstæn ɪleɪnz fɔɹm ə liɾɝʃɪp. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə sɪmpəl liɾɝʃɪp ʌv ə ɡɹup ə meɪɾənz ɑn ə ɹeɪd - ðət wɑz boʊθ ɪnstɪŋktɪv ən ɪfɪʃənt. ɪleɪn wəd nɑt wɑtʃ ðiz ɹɛfjudʒiz fəɹ saɪnz ə deɪnʒɝ əɹ hɪɾən soʊlʒɝz. ɪleɪn wəd fil ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi tə ðɛm, ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ə hɝ oʊn pipəl. ʃi wəd faɪn ə weɪ tə sɛn fud, pɝhæps juz əɹ tʃɹups tə sɪkjʊɹ ə seɪf ɛɹiə fəɹ əm tə hoʊmstɛd - ən ɪn duɪŋ soʊ, əkwaɪɝ ə pis ə ðɪs kʌntʃɹi fəɹ hɝsɛlf.

Watching these refugees, Aviendha tried to see them as Elayne would, but she still struggled to understand Elayne's form of leadership. It was not the simple leadership of a group of Maidens on a raid - that was both instinctive and efficient. Elayne would not watch these refugees for signs of danger or hidden soldiers. Elayne would feel a responsibility to them, even if they were not of her own people. She would find a way to send food, perhaps use her troops to secure a safe area for them to homestead - and in doing so, acquire a piece of this country for herself.

wʌns, eɪvinhə wʊɾə lɛf ðiz θɔts tə klæn tʃifs ən ɹufməstʃɹɛsəz. bʌt ʃi wɑzn ə meɪɾən ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, ən ʃi hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðæt. ʃi naʊ lɪvd ʌndɝ ə dɪfɹən ɹuf. ʃi wɑz əʃeɪm ðət ʃi hæd ɹɪzɪstɪd ðə tʃeɪnʒ fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ.

Once, Aviendha would have left these thoughts to clan chiefs and roofmistresses. But she wasn't a Maiden any longer, and she had accepted that. She now lived under a different roof. She was ashamed that she had resisted the change for so long.

bʌt ðət lɛft əɹ wɪð ə pɹɑbləm. wʌɾ ɑnɝ wɑz ðəɹ fəɹ əɹ naʊ? noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə meɪɾən, nɑt kwaɪɾ ə waɪz wʌn. hɝ ɪntaɪɝ aɪdɛntəɾi hæd bɪn ɹæpt ʌp ɪn ðoʊz spɪɹz, hɝ sɛlf fɔɹdʒd ɪndə ðɛɹ stil əz ʃʊɹli əz ðə kɑɹbən ðət stʃɹɛŋθən ðɛm. ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn fɹəm tʃaɪldhʊd sɝɾən ðət ʃi wəd bi fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ. ɪndid, ʃi hæd dʒɔɪn ðə meɪɾənz əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ʃi hæd bɪn pɹaʊɾ ə hɝ laɪf ən ə hɝ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz. ʃi wʊɾə sɝvd əɹ klæn ən sɛpt əntɪl ðə deɪ wən ʃi faɪnəli fɛl tə ðə spɪɹ, bliɾɪŋ əɹ læst wɔɾɝ ɑntu ðə pɑɹtʃt ɝθ ə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd.

But that left her with a problem. What honor was there for her now? No longer a Maiden, not quite a Wise One. Her entire identity had been wrapped up in those spears, her self forged into their steel as surely as the carbon that strengthened them. She had grown from childhood certain that she would be Far Dareis Mai. Indeed, she had joined the Maidens as soon as possible. She had been proud of her life and of her spear-sisters. She would have served her clan and sept until the day when she finally fell to the spear, bleeding her last water onto the parched earth of the Three-fold Land.

ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd, ən ʃi hæd hɝd səm ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ði il wəɾ ɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn ðɛɹ. ðɛɹ laɪvz hæd tʃeɪnʒd. ʃi dɪdn tʃɹʌs tʃeɪnʒ. ɪt kʊdn bi spɑɾəd əɹ stæbd; ɪt wɑz mɔɹ saɪlən ðən ɛni skaʊt, mɔɹ dɛdli ðən ɛni əsæsən. noʊ, ʃid nɛvɝ tʃɹʌst ɪt, bʌt ʃi wəɾ æksɛpt ɪt. ʃi wəd lɝn ɪleɪnz weɪz ən haʊ tə θɪŋk laɪk ə tʃif.

This was not the Three-fold Land, and she had heard some algai'd'siswai wonder if the Aiel would ever return there. Their lives had changed. She didn't trust change. It couldn't be spotted or stabbed; it was more silent than any scout, more deadly than any assassin. No, she'd never trust it, but she would accept it. She would learn Elayne's ways and how to think like a chief.

ʃi wəd faɪn ɑnɝ ɪn əɹ nu laɪf. sʌmhaʊ.

She would find honor in her new life. Somehow.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊ θɹɛt," wɪspɝɾ ɛɹn, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ wɪð ðə tʃɹu blʌdz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə meɪɾənz.

"They are no threat," whispered Heirn, crouching with the True Bloods on the other side of the Maidens.

ɹəɑɹk wɑtʃt ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz, əlɝt. "ðə dɛd wɔk," ðə tɑɹdæd klæn tʃif sɛd, "æn mɛn fɔl ət ɹændəm tə saɪtblɪndɝz ivəl, ðɛɹ blʌd kɝʌptɪd laɪk ðə wɔɾɝ ʌv ə bæd wɛl. ðoʊz maɪt bi pʊɹ foʊk fliɪŋ ðə ɹævɪdʒɪz ʌv wɔɹ. əɹ ðeɪ maɪt bi sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. wi kip əɹ dɪstəns."

Rhuarc watched the refugees, alert. "The dead walk," the Taardad clan chief said, "and men fall at random to Sightblinder's evil, their blood corrupted like the water of a bad well. Those might be poor folk fleeing the ravages of war. Or they might be something else. We keep our distance."

eɪvinhə ɡlænst ət ði ɪnkɹisɪŋli dɪstən laɪn ə ɹɛfjudʒiz. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɹəɑɹk wɑz ɹaɪt;

Aviendha glanced at the increasingly distant line of refugees. She did not think Rhuarc was right;

ðiz wɝ nɑt ɡoʊsts əɹ mɑnstɝz. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz sʌmθɪŋ . . . ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ðoʊz. ðeɪ lɛft əɹ wɪð ən ɪtʃ, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ əbaʊt tə bi ətækt.

these were not ghosts or monsters. There was always something . . . wrong about those. They left her with an itch, as if she were about to be attacked.

stɪl, ɹəɑɹk wɑz waɪz. wʌn lɝn tə bi kɛɹfəl ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd, wɛɹ ə taɪni twɪɡ kəd kɪl. ðə ɡɹup ʌv il slɪpt ɔf ðə hɪltɑp ən daʊn ɑntu ðə bɹaʊn-ɡɹæs pleɪn bɪɑnd. ivən æftɝ mʌnθs spɛn ɪn ðə wɛtlænz, eɪvinhə faʊn ðə lændskeɪp stʃɹeɪnʒ. tʃɹiz hɪɹ wɝ tɔl ən lɔŋ-lɪmd, wɪð tu mɛni bʌdz. wən ði il kɹɔs pætʃəz ə jɛloʊ spɹɪŋ ɡɹæs əmʌŋ ðə fɔlən wɪntɝ livz, ðeɪ ɔl sim soʊ fʊl ʌv wɔɾɝ ðət ʃi hæf-ɪkspɛktəd ðə bleɪdz ən livz tə bɝs bɪniθ əɹ fit. ʃi nu ðə wɛtləndɝz sɛd ðət ðɪs spɹɪŋ wɑz ənnətʃɝəli sloʊ stɑɹɾɪŋ, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪt wɑz mɔɹ fɝɾəl ðən əɹ hoʊmlænd.

Still, Rhuarc was wise. One learned to be careful in the Three-fold Land, where a tiny twig could kill. The group of Aiel slipped off the hilltop and down onto the brown-grassed plain beyond. Even after months spent in the wetlands, Aviendha found the landscape strange. Trees here were tall and long-limbed, with too many buds. When the Aiel crossed patches of yellow spring grass among the fallen winter leaves, they all seemed so full of water that she half-expected the blades and leaves to burst beneath her feet. She knew the wetlanders said that this spring was unnaturally slow starting, but already it was more fertile than her homeland.

ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd, ðɪs mɛdoʊ - wɪð ðə hɪlz tə pɹəvaɪd wɑtʃpɔɪns ən ʃɛltɝ - wəɾ əv ɪmiɾiətli bɪn siz baɪ ə sɛpt ən juz fəɹ fɑɹmɪŋ. hɪɹ, ɪt wɑz dʒʌst wʌn ʌv ə θaʊzən dɪfɹən əntʌtʃt pætʃəz ə lænd. ðə fɔlt leɪ əɡɛn ɪn ðoʊz sɪɾiz. ðə nɪɹəst wʌnz wɝ tu dɪstən fɹəm ðɪs loʊkeɪʃən tə meɪk ɪɾ ə ɡʊd spɑt fəɹ ə wɛtləndɝ fɑɹmstɛd.

In the Three-fold Land, this meadow - with the hills to provide watchpoints and shelter - would have immediately been seized by a sept and used for farming. Here, it was just one of a thousand different untouched patches of land. The fault lay again in those cities. The nearest ones were too distant from this location to make it a good spot for a wetlander farmstead.

ði eɪɾ il kwɪkli kɹɔs ðə ɡɹæsəz, wivɪŋ bɪtwin hɪlsaɪdz, muvɪŋ wɪð spiɾ ən stɛlθ. hɔɹsəz kəd nɑt mætʃ ə mænz fit, wʌt wɪð ðɛɹ θʌndɝəs ɡæləpɪŋ. tɛɹəbəl bists -  waɪ dɪd ðə wɛtləndɝz ɪnsɪst ɑn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðɛm? bæfəlɪŋ. eɪvinhə kəd bɪɡɪn tə ʌndɝstæn haʊ ə tʃif əɹ kwin mʌs θɪŋk, bʌt ʃi nu ðət ʃid nɛvɝ kəmplitli ʌndɝstænd wɛtləndɝz. ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs tu stʃɹeɪnʒ. ivən ɹænd ælθɹ.

The eight Aiel quickly crossed the grasses, weaving between hillsides, moving with speed and stealth. Horses could not match a man's feet, what with their thunderous galloping. Terrible beasts -  why did the wetlanders insist on riding them? Baffling. Aviendha could begin to understand how a chief or queen must think, but she knew that she'd never completely understand wetlanders. They were just too strange. Even Rand al'Thor.

ɪspɛʃli ɹænd ælθɹ. ʃi smaɪld, θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɪz ɝnɪst aɪz. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə sɛn ə hɪm - wɛtləndɝ soʊps, wɪtʃ smɛld ʌv ɔɪl, mɪkst wɪð ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɝθi mʌsk ðət wɑz ɔl ɪz oʊn. ʃi wəd mɛɹi hɪm. ʃi wɑz əz dɪtɝmən əz ɪleɪn ɪn ðət ɹəɡɑɹd; naʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ fɝst- sɪstɝz, ðeɪ kəd mɛɹi hɪm təɡɛðɝ əz wɑz pɹɑpɝ. oʊnli, haʊ kəɾ eɪvinhə mɛɹi ɛniwʌn, naʊ?

Especially Rand al'Thor. She smiled, thinking of his earnest eyes. She remembered the scent of him - wetlander soaps, which smelled of oil, mixed with that particular earthy musk that was all his own. She would marry him. She was as determined as Elayne in that regard; now that they were first- sisters, they could marry him together as was proper. Only, how could Aviendha marry anyone, now?

hɝ ɑnɝ hæd bɪn ɪn əɹ spɪɹz, bʌt ɹænd ælθɹ naʊ wɔɹ ðoʊz əɾ ɪz weɪst, biɾən ən fɔɹdʒd ɪndə ə bɛl bʌkəl, ɡɪvən tə hɪm baɪ hɝ oʊn hænd.

Her honor had been in her spears, but Rand al'Thor now wore those at his waist, beaten and forged into a belt buckle, given to him by her own hand.

hi hæɾ ɔfɝɾ əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ wʌns. ə mæn! ɔfɝɪŋ mɛɹɪdʒ! ənʌðɝ ə ðoʊz stʃɹeɪnʒ wɛtləndɝ kʌstəmz. ivən dɪsɹɪɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ʌv ɪt - dɪsɹɪɡɑɹɾɪŋ ði ɪnsʌlt ɪz pɹəpoʊzəl hæd ʃoʊn ɪleɪn - eɪvinhə kəd nɛvɝ əv æksɛptɪd ɹænd ælθɹ əz əɹ hʌzbənd. kʊdn i ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ ə wʊmən mʌs bɹɪŋ ɑnɝ tə ə mɛɹɪdʒ? wʌt kəɾ ə mɪɹ əpɹɛntəs ɔfɝ? wəɾ i hæv əɹ kʌm tə hɪm əz ən ɪnfɪɹiɝ? ɪt wəd ʃeɪm əɹ kəmplitli tə də ðæt!

He had offered her marriage once. A man! Offering marriage! Another of those strange wetlander customs. Even disregarding the strangeness of it - disregarding the insult his proposal had shown Elayne - Aviendha could never have accepted Rand al'Thor as her husband. Couldn't he understand that a woman must bring honor to a marriage? What could a mere apprentice offer? Would he have her come to him as an inferior? It would shame her completely to do that!

hi mʌs nɑɾ əv ʌndɝstʊd. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪm kɹuəl, oʊnli dɛns. ʃi wəd kʌm tə hɪm wən ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi, ðən leɪ ðə bɹaɪɾəl ɹiθ əɾ ɪz fit. ən ʃi kʊdn də ðəɾ əntɪl ʃi nu hu ʃi wɑz.

He must not have understood. She did not think him cruel, only dense. She would come to him when she was ready, then lay the bridal wreath at his feet. And she couldn't do that until she knew who she was.

ðə weɪz ə dʒiɾoʊ wɝ kɑmplɛks. eɪvinhə nu haʊ tə mɛʒɝ ɑnɝ əz ə meɪɾən, bʌt waɪz wʌnz wɝ dɪfɹən kɹitʃɝz ɪntaɪɝli. ʃi hæd θɔt ʃi wɑz ɡeɪnɪŋ səm smɔl əmaʊn ʌv ɑnɝ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. ðeɪ hæɾ əlaʊd hɝ, fəɹ ɪnstəns, tə spɛn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm wɪð əɹ fɝst-sɪstɝ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. bʌt ðɛn, sʌɾənli, dɔɹinhə ən neɪdɪɹ hæɾ ɝaɪvd ən ɪnfɔɹmd eɪvinhə ðət ʃi hæd bɪn ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ əɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd sizd əɹ laɪk ə tʃaɪl kɑt lɪsnɪŋ fɝɾɪvli aʊtsaɪd ðə swɛt tɛnt, toʊɪŋ əɹ əweɪ tə dʒɔɪn ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ klæn əz ðeɪ lɛft fəɹ ɑɹæd dumən.

The ways of ji'e'toh were complex. Aviendha knew how to measure honor as a Maiden, but Wise Ones were different creatures entirely. She had thought she was gaining some small amount of honor in their eyes. They had allowed her, for instance, to spend a great deal of time with her first-sister in Caemlyn. But then, suddenly, Dorindha and Nadere had arrived and informed Aviendha that she had been ignoring her training. They had seized her like a child caught listening furtively outside the sweat tent, towing her away to join the rest of her clan as they left for Arad Doman.

ən naʊ . . . ən naʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz tʃɹiɾəd əɹ wɪð lɛs ɹɪspɛk ðən ðeɪ hæd bɪfɔɹ! ðeɪ ɔfɝɾ əɹ noʊ titʃɪŋ. sʌmhaʊ, ʃi hæd mɪsstɛpt ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. ðət meɪɾ əɹ stʌmək twɪst. tə ʃeɪm hɝsɛlf bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz ʃoʊɪŋ fɪɹ bɪfɔɹ wʌn əz bɹeɪv əz ɪleɪn!

And now . . . and now the Wise Ones treated her with less respect than they had before! They offered her no teaching. Somehow, she had misstepped in their eyes. That made her stomach twist. To shame herself before the other Wise Ones was almost as bad as showing fear before one as brave as Elayne!

soʊ fɑɹ, ðə waɪz wʌnz hæɾ əlaʊɾ eɪvinhə səm ɑnɝ baɪ lɛɾɪŋ əɹ sɝv pʌnɪʃməns, bʌt ʃi dɪdnt noʊ haʊ ʃi hæd ʃeɪm hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. æskɪŋ wəd - ʌv kɔɹs - oʊnli bɹɪŋ mɔɹ ʃeɪm. əntɪl ʃi ənwʌv ðə pɹɑbləm, ʃi kəd nɑt miɾ əɹ toʊ. wɝs, ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹil deɪnʒɝ ə hɝ meɪkɪŋ ðə mɪsteɪk əɡɛn. əntɪl ʃi sɔɹɾɪd aʊt ðɪs pɹɑbləm, ʃi wəd ɹɪmeɪn ən əpɹɛntəs, ən ʃi wəd nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə bɹɪŋ ən ɑnɝəbəl bɹaɪɾəl ɹiθ tə ɹænd ælθɹ.

So far, the Wise Ones had allowed Aviendha some honor by letting her serve punishments, but she didn't know how she had shamed herself in the first place. Asking would - of course - only bring more shame. Until she unwove the problem, she could not meet her toh. Worse, there was a real danger of her making the mistake again. Until she sorted out this problem, she would remain an apprentice, and she would never be able to bring an honorable bridal wreath to Rand al'Thor.

eɪvinhə ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. ənʌðɝ wʊmən maɪɾ əv wɛpt, bʌt wʌt ɡʊd wəd ðəɾ əv dʌn? wʌtɛvɝ əɹ mɪsteɪk, ʃi hæd bɹɔɾ ɪɾ əpɑn hɝsɛlf, ən ɪt wɑz əɹ duɾi tə ɹaɪɾ ɪt. ʃi wəd faɪn ɑnɝ əɡɛn ən ʃi wəd mɛɹi ɹænd ælθɹ bɪfɔɹ i daɪɾ ət ðə læs bæɾəl.

Aviendha gritted her teeth. Another woman might have wept, but what good would that have done? Whatever her mistake, she had brought it upon herself, and it was her duty to right it. She would find honor again and she would marry Rand al'Thor before he died at the Last Battle.

ðət mɛn ðət wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ʃi hæd tə lɝn, ʃi niɾəd tə də soʊ kwɪkli. vɛɹi kwɪkli.

That meant that whatever it was she had to learn, she needed to do so quickly. Very quickly.

ðeɪ mɛɾ ʌp wɪð ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ʌv il weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ əmɪɾ ə stæn ə paɪn tʃɹiz. ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz θɪk wɪð dɪskɑɹɾɪd bɹaʊn niɾəlz, ðə skaɪ bɹoʊkən baɪ ðə taʊɝɪŋ tʃɹʌŋks. ðə ɡɹup wɑz smɔl baɪ ðə stændɝdz ə klænz ən sɛps, bɛɹli tu hʌnʒɹəd pipəl. ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ stʊd fɔɹ waɪz wʌnz, itʃ wɛɹɪŋ ðə kɛɹəktɝɪstɪk bɹaʊn wʊlən skɝɾ ən waɪt blaʊs.

They met up with another group of Aiel waiting in a small clearing amid a stand of pine trees. The ground was thick with discarded brown needles, the sky broken by the towering trunks. The group was small by the standards of clans and septs, barely two hundred people. In the middle of the clearing stood four Wise Ones, each wearing the characteristic brown woolen skirt and white blouse.

eɪvinhə wɔɹ sɪməlɝ ətaɪɝ, wɪtʃ naʊ fɛlt əz nætʃɹəl tə hɝ əz ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ wʌns hæd. ðə skaʊɾɪŋ pɑɹɾi splɪɾ ʌp, mɛn ən meɪɾənz muvɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn mɛmbɝz ə ðɛɹ klænz əɹ səsaɪəɾiz. ɹəɑɹk dʒɔɪn ðə waɪz wʌnz, ən eɪvinhə fɑloʊd hɪm.

Aviendha wore similar attire, which now felt as natural to her as the cadin'sor once had. The scouting party split up, men and Maidens moving to join members of their clans or societies. Rhuarc joined the Wise Ones, and Aviendha followed him.

itʃ ə ðə waɪz wʌnz - æmɪz, bɛɹ, məleɪn, ən neɪdɪɹ - ɡeɪv əɹ ə ɡlæns. bɛɹ, ði oʊnli il wɪð ðə ɡɹup u wɑzn tɑɹdæɾ əɹ ɡoʊʃin, hæɾ ɝaɪvd oʊnli ɹisənli, pɝhæps tə koʊɔɹɾəneɪt wɪð ði ʌðɝz. wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɹizən, nʌn ə ðɛm sim plizd. eɪvinhə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɪf ʃi lɛf naʊ, wəɾ ɪt sim əz ɪf ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əvɔɪd ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən? dɪd ʃi ɪnstɛd dɛɹ steɪ, ən ɹɪsk ɪnkɝɪŋ ðɛɹ fɝðɝ dɪsplɛʒɝ?

Each of the Wise Ones - Amys, Bair, Melaine, and Nadere - gave her a glance. Bair, the only Aiel with the group who wasn't Taardad or Goshien, had arrived only recently, perhaps to coordinate with the others. Whatever the reason, none of them seemed pleased. Aviendha hesitated. If she left now, would it seem as if she were trying to avoid their attention? Did she instead dare stay, and risk incurring their further displeasure?

"wɛl?" æmɪz sɛd tə ɹəɑɹk. ðoʊ æmɪz hæd waɪt hɛɹ, ʃi lʊkt kwaɪt jʌŋ. ɪn əɹ keɪs, ðɪs wɑzn du tə wɝkɪŋ ðə paʊɝ - hɝ hɛɹ hæd stɑɹɾəd tɝnɪŋ sɪlvɝ wən ʃid bɪn ə tʃaɪld.

"Well?" Amys said to Rhuarc. Though Amys had white hair, she looked quite young. In her case, this wasn't due to working the Power - her hair had started turning silver when she'd been a child.

"ɪt wɑz əz ðə skaʊts dɪskɹaɪbd, ʃeɪɾ ə maɪ hɑɹt," ɹəɑɹk sɛd. "ənʌðɝ pɪɾəfəl bæn ʌv wɛtləndɝ ɹɛfjudʒiz. aɪ sɔ noʊ hɪɾən deɪnʒɝ ɪn ðɛm."

"It was as the scouts described, shade of my heart," Rhuarc said. "Another pitiful band of wetlander refugees. I saw no hidden danger in them."

ðə waɪz wʌnz nɑɾəd, əz ɪf ðɪs wɑz wʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. "ðæɾ ɪz ðə tɛnθ bæn ə ɹɛfjudʒiz ɪn lɛs ðən ə wik," sɛɾ eɪdʒ bɛɹ, hɝ wɔɾɝi blu aɪz θɔtfəl.

The Wise Ones nodded, as if this was what they had expected. "That is the tenth band of refugees in less than a week," said aged Bair, her watery blue eyes thoughtful.

ɹəɑɹk nɑɾəd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɹumɝz ə sintʃæn ətæks ɑn hɑɹbɝz tə ðə wɛst. pɝhæps ðə pipəl muv ɪnlæn tə əvɔɪd ðə ɹeɪdz." hi ɡlænst əɾ æmɪz. "ðɪs kʌntʃɹi bɔɪlz laɪk wɔɾɝ spɪld ɑn ə hɑɹθstoʊn. ðə klænz ɑɹ ənsɝɾən wʌt ɹænd ælθɹ wɪʃɪz ə ðɛm."

Rhuarc nodded. "There are rumors of Seanchan attacks on harbors to the west. Perhaps the people move inland to avoid the raids." He glanced at Amys. "This country boils like water spilled on a hearthstone. The clans are uncertain what Rand al'Thor wishes of them."

"hi wɑz vɛɹi klɪɹ," bɛɹ noʊɾəd. "hi wɪl bi pliz ðət jə ən dɑbɹeɪn tæbɔɹwɪn sɪkjʊɹd bændɑɹ ɛbən, əz i æskt."

"He was very clear," Bair noted. "He will be pleased that you and Dobraine Taborwin secured Bandar Eban, as he asked."

ɹəɑɹk nɑɾəd. "bʌt stɪl, hɪz ɪntɛntʃənz ɑɹ nɑt klɪɹ. hi æsk fəɹ əs tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ. ɑɹ wi ðən tə bi laɪk wɛtləndɝ sɪɾi ɡɑɹdzmɪn? ðəɾ ɪz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ ði il. wəɹ nɑt tə kɑŋkɝ, soʊ wi də nɑt ɡɛt ðə fɪfθ. ən jɛɾ ɪt filz vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk kɑŋkwɛst, wʌt wi du. ðə kɑɹəkɑɹnz ɔɹɾɝz kən bi klɪɹ jɛt kənfjuzɪŋ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. hiz ə ɡɪft ɪn ðəɾ ɛɹiə, aɪ θɪŋk."

Rhuarc nodded. "But still, his intentions are not clear. He asked for us to restore order. Are we then to be like wetlander city guardsmen? That is no place for the Aiel. We are not to conquer, so we do not get the fifth. And yet it feels very much like conquest, what we do. The Car'a'carn's orders can be clear yet confusing at the same time. He has a gift in that area, I think."

bɛɹ smaɪld, nɑɾɪŋ. "pɝhæps i ɪntɛnz fəɹ əs tə də sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ðiz ɹɛfjudʒiz."

Bair smiled, nodding. "Perhaps he intends for us to do something with these refugees."

"ænd wʌt wəd wi du?" æmɪz æskt, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "ɑɹ wi ʃeɪɾoʊ, ɪkspɛktəd tə meɪk ɡeɪʃeɪn fɹəm wɛtləndɝz?" hɝ toʊn lɛf lɪɾəl daʊɾ əz tə wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə boʊθ ʃeɪɾoʊ ən ði aɪdiə ʌv meɪkɪŋ wɛtləndɝz ɡeɪʃeɪn.

"And what would we do?" Amys asked, shaking her head. "Are we Shaido, expected to make gai'shain from wetlanders?" Her tone left little doubt as to what she thought of both Shaido and the idea of making wetlanders gai'shain.

eɪvinhə nɑɾəd ɪn əɡɹimənt. əz ɹəɑɹk sɛd, ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn hæd sɛn əm tə ɑɹæd dumən tə "ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ." bʌt ðət wɑz ə wɛtləndɝ kɑnsɛpt; il bɹɔt ðɛɹ oʊn ɔɹɾɝ wɪð ðɛm. ðəɹ wɑz keɪɑs tə wɔɹ ən bæɾəl, tʃɹu, bʌɾ itʃ ən ɛvɹi il ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪz pleɪs, ən wəɾ ækt wɪðɪn ðət pleɪs. ðə lɪɾəl tʃɪlʒɹən ʌndɝstʊɾ ɑnɝ ən toʊ, ən ə hoʊld wəd kəntɪnju tə fʌŋkʃən æftɝ ɔl ə ðə liɾɝz ən waɪz wʌnz wɝ kɪld.

Aviendha nodded in agreement. As Rhuarc said, the Car'a'carn had sent them to Arad Doman to "restore order." But that was a wetlander concept; Aiel brought their own order with them. There was chaos to war and battle, true, but each and every Aiel understood his place, and would act within that place. The little children understood honor and toh, and a hold would continue to function after all of the leaders and Wise Ones were killed.

ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ wɪð wɛtləndɝz. ðeɪ ɹæn əbaʊt laɪk ə bæskəɾ ʌv waɪld lɪzɝdz sʌɾənli dʒɹɑpt ɑntu hɑt stoʊnz, teɪkɪŋ noʊ kɛɹ fəɹ pɹəvɪʒənz wən ðeɪ flɛd. əz sun əz ðɛɹ liɾɝz wɝ ɑkjəpaɪɾ əɹ dɪstʃɹæktəd, bændətʃɹi ən keɪɑs ɹuld. ðə stʃɹɔŋ tʊk fɹəm ðə wik, ən ivən blæksmɪθs wɝ nɑt seɪf.

It was not so with wetlanders. They ran about like a basket of wild lizards suddenly dropped onto hot stones, taking no care for provisions when they fled. As soon as their leaders were occupied or distracted, banditry and chaos ruled. The strong took from the weak, and even blacksmiths were not safe.

wʌt kəd ɹænd ælθɹ ɪkspɛk ði il tə də əbaʊɾ ɪt? ðeɪ kəd nɑt titʃ dʒiɾoʊ tə ən ɪntaɪɝ neɪʃən. ɹænd ælθɹ hæd toʊld əm tə əvɔɪd kɪlɪŋ dəmɑni tʃɹups. bʌt ðoʊz tʃɹups - ɔfən kɝʌpt ən tɝn tə bændətʃɹi ðɛmsɛlvz - wɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə pɹɑbləm.

What could Rand al'Thor expect the Aiel to do about it? They could not teach ji'e'toh to an entire nation. Rand al'Thor had told them to avoid killing Domani troops. But those troops - often corrupt and turned to banditry themselves - were part of the problem.

"pɝhæps hɪl ɪkspleɪn mɔɹ wən wi ɝaɪv ət ðɪs mænɝ haʊs ə hɪz," sɛd məleɪn, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ kætʃɪŋ ðə laɪt. hɝ pɹɛɡnənsi wɑz dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃoʊ bɪniθ əɹ waɪz wʌn blaʊs. "æn ɪf i dʌz nɑt, ðən ʃʊɹli ɪts bɛɾɝ fəɹ əs tə bi hɪɹ ɪn ɑɹæd dumən ðən tə spɛn jɛt mɔɹ taɪm laʊnʒɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə læn ə ðə tʃɹikɪlɝz."

"Perhaps he will explain more when we arrive at this manor house of his," said Melaine, shaking her head, red-gold hair catching the light. Her pregnancy was just beginning to show beneath her Wise One blouse. "And if he does not, then surely it is better for us to be here in Arad Doman than to spend yet more time lounging back in the land of the treekillers."

"æz jə seɪ," ɹəɑɹk əɡɹid. "lɛɾ əs muv ɑn, ðɛn. ðəɹ ɪz stɪl ə dɪstəns tə ɹʌn." hi muvd ɔf tə spik wɪð beɪl. eɪvinhə tʊk ə stɛp əweɪ, bʌɾ ə hɑɹʃ ɡlæns fɹəm æmɪz meɪɾ əɹ fɹiz.

"As you say," Rhuarc agreed. "Let us move on, then. There is still a distance to run." He moved off to speak with Bael. Aviendha took a step away, but a harsh glance from Amys made her freeze.

"eɪvinhə," sɛd ðə hɑɹd, waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən. "haʊ mɛni waɪz wʌnz wɛnt wɪð ɹəɑɹk tə skaʊt ðɪs ɹɛfjʊdʒi tʃɹeɪn?"

"Aviendha," said the hard, white-haired woman. "How many Wise Ones went with Rhuarc to scout this refugee train?"

"nʌn bʌt mi," eɪvinhə ədmɪɾəd.

"None but me," Aviendha admitted.

"oʊ, ən ɑɹ jə ə waɪz wʌn naʊ?" bɛɹ æskt.

"Oh, and are you a Wise One now?" Bair asked.

"noʊ," eɪvinhə sɛd, kwɪkli, ðən ʃeɪm hɝsɛlf fɝðɝ baɪ blʌʃɪŋ. "aɪ spoʊk pʊɹli."

"No," Aviendha said, quickly, then shamed herself further by blushing. "I spoke poorly."

"ðɛn jə ʃæl bi pʌnɪʃt," bɛɹ sɛd. "ju ɑɹ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə meɪɾən, eɪvinhə. ɪts nɑt jəɹ pleɪs tə skaʊt; ðəɾ ɪz ə tæsk fəɹ ʌðɝz."

"Then you shall be punished," Bair said. "You are no longer a Maiden, Aviendha. It is not your place to scout; that is a task for others."

"jɛs, waɪz wʌn," eɪvinhə sɛd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn. ʃi hæd nɑt θɔt ðət ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð ɹəɑɹk wəd bɹɪŋ əɹ ʃeɪm - ʃi hæd sin ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz də sɪməlɝ tæsks.

"Yes, Wise One," Aviendha said, looking down. She had not thought that going with Rhuarc would bring her shame - she had seen other Wise Ones do similar tasks.

bʌɾ aɪm nɑɾ ə waɪz wʌn, ʃi ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf. aɪm ən əpɹɛntəs oʊnli. bɛɹ hæd nɑt sɛd ðəɾ ə waɪz wʌn kəd nɑt skaʊt; oʊnli ðəɾ ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn eɪvinhəz pleɪs tə ɡoʊ. ɪt wɑz əbaʊɾ eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf. ən əbaʊt wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ʃi hæd dʌn - əɹ pɝhæps kəntɪnjud tə də - tə pɹəvoʊk ðə waɪz wʌnz.

But I am not a Wise One, she reminded herself. I am an apprentice only. Bair had not said that a Wise One could not scout; only that it had not been Aviendha's place to go.
