It was about Aviendha herself. And about whatever it was she had done - or perhaps continued to do - to provoke the Wise Ones.

dɪd ðeɪ θɪŋk ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn sɑf baɪ spɛndɪŋ taɪm wɪð ɪleɪn? eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf wɝid ðət ðət wɑz tʃɹu. dʊɹɪŋ əɹ deɪz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə faɪn hɝsɛlf ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə sɪlks ən bæθs.

Did they think she had grown soft by spending time with Elayne? Aviendha herself worried that that was true. During her days in Caemlyn, she had begun to find herself enjoying the silks and baths.

baɪ ði ɛnd, ʃi hæɾ əbdʒɛktəɾ oʊnli fibli wən ɪleɪn hæd kʌm ʌp wɪð ən ɪkskjus tə dʒɹɛs əɹ ɪn səm ɪmpɹæktəkəl ən fɹɪvələs ɡɑɹmənt wɪð ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən leɪs. ɪt wɑz wɛl ðət ði ʌðɝz hæd kʌm fəɹ hɝ.

By the end, she had objected only feebly when Elayne had come up with an excuse to dress her in some impractical and frivolous garment with embroidery and lace. It was well that the others had come for her.

ði ʌðɝz dʒʌst stʊd ðɛɹ, lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɪkspɛktənli, feɪsəz laɪk ɹɛd dɛzɝt stoʊnz, ɪmpæsɪv ən stɝn. eɪvinhə ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ əɡɛn. ʃi wəd kəmpliɾ əɹ əpɹɛntəsʃɪp ən faɪn ɑnɝ. ʃi wʊd.

The others just stood there, looking at her expectantly, faces like red desert stones, impassive and stern. Aviendha gritted her teeth again. She would complete her apprenticeship and find honor. She would.

ðə kɔl keɪm tə bɪɡɪn muvɪŋ, ən keɪɾɪnsɝ-klæd mɛn ən wɪmən dɪd soʊ, ɹʌnɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ɪn smɔl ɡɹups. ðə waɪz wʌnz muvd əz izəli əz ðə soʊlʒɝz, dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ bʌlki skɝts. æmɪz tʌtʃt eɪvinhəz ɑɹm. "ju wɪl ɹʌn wɪð mi soʊ ðət wi kən dɪskʌs jəɹ pʌnɪʃmənt."

The call came to begin moving, and cadin'sor-clad men and women did so, running together in small groups. The Wise Ones moved as easily as the soldiers, despite their bulky skirts. Amys touched Aviendha's arm. "You will run with me so that we can discuss your punishment."

eɪvinhə fɛl ɪndə peɪs bɪsaɪd ðə waɪz wʌn əɾ ə bɹɪsk dʒɑɡ. ɪt wɑz ə spiɾ ɛni il kəd meɪnteɪn ɔlmoʊst ɪndɛfənətli. hɝ ɡɹup, fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn, hæd mɛɾ ʌp wɪð ɹəɑɹk əz i wɑz tʃɹævlɪŋ fɹəm bændɑɹ ɛbən tə mit wɪð ɹænd ælθɹ ɪn ðə wɛstɝn pɑɹɾ ə ðə kʌntʃɹi. dɑbɹeɪn tæbɔɹwɪn, ə kɛɹhinɪn, wɑz stɪl meɪnteɪnɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ ɪn ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi, wɛɹ hid ɹɪpɔɹɾədli loʊkeɪɾəd ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə dəmɑni ɹulɪŋ bɑɾi.

Aviendha fell into pace beside the Wise One at a brisk jog. It was a speed any Aiel could maintain almost indefinitely. Her group, from Caemlyn, had met up with Rhuarc as he was traveling from Bandar Eban to meet with Rand al'Thor in the western part of the country. Dobraine Taborwin, a Cairhienin, was still maintaining order in the capital city, where he'd reportedly located a member of the Domani ruling body.

pɝhæps ðə ɡɹup ʌv il cʊɾə tʃɹævəl θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə dɪstəns. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt fɑɹ - oʊnli ə fju deɪz baɪ fʊt - ən ðeɪ hæd lɛft ɝli ɪnʌf tə ɝaɪv ət ði əpɔɪntəd taɪm wɪθaʊt juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɹəɑɹk wɑntəd tə skaʊt fəɹ hɪmsɛlf səm ə ðə lændskeɪp nɪɹ ðə mænɝ haʊs ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz juzɪŋ əz ə beɪs. ʌðɝ bɑɾiz ʌv ɡoʊʃin əɹ tɑɹdæɾ il wəd dʒɔɪn əm ət ðə beɪs, juzɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz, ɪf niɾəd.

Perhaps the group of Aiel could have Traveled through a gateway the rest of the distance. But it was not far - only a few days by foot - and they had left early enough to arrive at the appointed time without using the One Power. Rhuarc wanted to scout for himself some of the landscape near the manor house Rand al'Thor was using as a base. Other bodies of Goshien or Taardad Aiel would join them at the base, using gateways, if needed.

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə ðə kɑɹəkɑɹnz dɪmænz ʌv əs hɪɹ ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, eɪvinhə?" æmɪz æskt əz ðeɪ ɹæn.

"What do you think of the Car'a'carn's demands of us here in Arad Doman, Aviendha?" Amys asked as they ran.

eɪvinhə staɪfəld ə fɹaʊn. wʌɾ ə hɝ pʌnɪʃmənt? "ɪɾ ɪz ən ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ ɹɪkwɛst," ʃi sɛd, "bʌt ɹænd ælθɹ əz mɛni stʃɹeɪnʒ aɪdiəz, ivən fəɹ ə wɛtləndɝ. ðɪs wɪl nɑt bi ðə moʊst ənjuʒəwəl duɾi hiz sɛt fəɹ ʌs."

Aviendha stifled a frown. What of her punishment? "It is an irregular request," she said, "but Rand al'Thor has many strange ideas, even for a wetlander. This will not be the most unusual duty he has set for us."

"æn ðə fæk ðət ɹəɑɹk faɪnz ðə duɾi dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋ?"

"And the fact that Rhuarc finds the duty discomforting?"

"aɪ daʊt ðət ðə klæn tʃif ɪz ənkʌmftəɹbəl," eɪvinhə sɛd. "aɪ səspɛk ðət ɹəɑɹk spiks wʌt hiz hɝɾ ʌðɝz seɪ, pæsɪŋ ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən tə ðə waɪz wʌnz. hi dʌz nɑt wɪʃ tə ʃeɪm ʌðɝz baɪ ɹɪvilɪŋ u hæz spoʊkən ə ðɛɹ fɪɹz."

"I doubt that the clan chief is uncomfortable," Aviendha said. "I suspect that Rhuarc speaks what he has heard others say, passing the information to the Wise Ones. He does not wish to shame others by revealing who has spoken of their fears."

æmɪz nɑɾəd. wʌt wɑz ðə pɝpəs ə ðə kwɛstʃənz? ʃʊɹli ðə wʊmən hæd ɡɛs ðə seɪm θɪŋ. ʃi wəd nɑt kʌm tə eɪvinhə fəɹ kaʊnsəl.

Amys nodded. What was the purpose of the questions? Surely the woman had guessed the same thing. She would not come to Aviendha for counsel.

ðeɪ ɹæn ɪn saɪləns fəɹ ə taɪm, wɪð noʊ mɛnʃən ə pʌnɪʃməns. hæd ðə waɪz wʌnz fɝɡɪvən əɹ ənnoʊn slaɪt? ʃʊɹli ðeɪ wʊdn dɪsɑnɝ əɹ ɪn ðət weɪ. eɪvinhə hæd tə bi ɡɪvən taɪm tə θɪŋk aʊt wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn, ʌðɝwaɪz əɹ ʃeɪm wəd bi ənbɛɹəbəl. ʃi maɪɾ ɛɹ əɡɛn, ðɪs taɪm wɝs.

They ran in silence for a time, with no mention of punishments. Had the Wise Ones forgiven her unknown slight? Surely they wouldn't dishonor her in that way. Aviendha had to be given time to think out what she had done, otherwise her shame would be unbearable. She might err again, this time worse.

æmɪz ɡeɪv noʊ klu əz tə hɝ θɔts. ðə waɪz wʌn hæd bɪn ə meɪɾən wʌns, laɪk eɪvinhə. ʃi wɑz hɑɹd, ivən fəɹ ən il. "æn ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf?" æmɪz æskt. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə hɪm?"

Amys gave no clue as to her thoughts. The Wise One had been a Maiden once, like Aviendha. She was hard, even for an Aiel. "And al'Thor himself?" Amys asked. "What do you think of him?"

"aɪ lʌv hɪm," eɪvinhə sɛd.

"I love him," Aviendha said.

"aɪ dɪd nɑɾ æsk eɪvinhə ðə sɪli ɡɝl," æmɪz sɛd kɝtli. "aɪ æskt eɪvinhə ðə waɪz wʌn."

"I did not ask Aviendha the silly girl," Amys said curtly. "I asked Aviendha the Wise One."

"hi ɪz ə mæn ə mɛni bɝɾənz," eɪvinhə sɛd mɔɹ kɛɹfəli. "aɪ fɪɹ ðəɾ i meɪks mɛni ʌv ðoʊz bɝɾənz hɛviɝ ðən ðeɪ nid bi. aɪ wʌns θɔt ðət ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə bi stʃɹɔŋ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv lɝn fɹəm maɪ fɝst-sɪstɝ ðəɾ aɪ wɑz ɹɔŋ. ɹænd ælθɹ . . . aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk hiz lɝn ðɪs jɛt. aɪ wɝi ðəɾ i mɪsteɪks hɑɹdnəs fəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ."

"He is a man of many burdens," Aviendha said more carefully. "I fear that he makes many of those burdens heavier than they need be. I once thought that there was only one way to be strong, but I have learned from my first-sister that I was wrong. Rand al'Thor . . . I do not think he has learned this yet. I worry that he mistakes hardness for strength."

æmɪz nɑɾəd əɡɛn, əz ɪf ɪn əpɹuvəl. wɝ ðiz kwɛstʃənz ə tɛst ə səm sɔɹt?

Amys nodded again, as if in approval. Were these questions a test of some sort?

"ju wəd mɛɹi hɪm?" æmɪz æskt.

"You would marry him?" Amys asked.

aɪ θɔt wi wɝn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ eɪvinhə ðə "sɪli ɡɝl," eɪvinhə θɔt, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs dɪdn seɪ ɪt. wʌn dɪd nɑt seɪ sətʃ θɪŋz tə æmɪz.

I thought we weren't talking about Aviendha the "silly girl," Aviendha thought, but of course didn't say it. One did not say such things to Amys.

"aɪ wɪl mɛɹi hɪm," ʃi sɛɾ ɪnstɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə pɑsəbɪləɾi, bʌɾ ə sɝɾənti." ðə toʊn ɝn əɹ ə ɡlæns fɹəm æmɪz, bʌɾ eɪvinhə hɛld əɹ ɡɹaʊnd. ɛni waɪz wʌn u mɪsspoʊk dɪzɝv tə bi kɝɛktəd.

"I will marry him," she said instead. "It is not a possibility, but a certainty." The tone earned her a glance from Amys, but Aviendha held her ground. Any Wise One who misspoke deserved to be corrected.

"æn ðə wɛtləndɝ mɪn fɑɹʃɔ?" æmɪz æskt. "ʃi ɑbviəsli lʌvz hɪm. wʌt wɪl jə də əbaʊt hɝ?"

"And the wetlander Min Farshaw?" Amys asked. "She obviously loves him. What will you do about her?"

"ʃi ɪz maɪ kənsɝn," eɪvinhə sɛd. "wi wɪl ɹitʃ ən əkɑmədeɪʃən. aɪ hæv spoʊkən wɪð mɪn fɑɹʃɔ, ən aɪ bɪliv ʃɪl bi izi tə wɝk wɪð."

"She is my concern," Aviendha said. "We will reach an accommodation. I have spoken with Min Farshaw, and I believe she will be easy to work with."

"ju wəd bɪkʌm fɝst-sɪstɝz wɪð əɹ əz wɛl?" æmɪz æskt, saʊndɪŋ dʒʌs feɪnli əmjuzd.

"You would become first-sisters with her as well?" Amys asked, sounding just faintly amused.

"wi wɪl ɹitʃ ən əkɑmədeɪʃən, waɪz wʌn."

"We will reach an accommodation, Wise One."

"æn ɪf jə kænɑt?"

"And if you cannot?"

"wi wɪl," eɪvinhə sɛd fɝmli.

"We will," Aviendha said firmly.

"æn haʊ kən jə bi soʊ sɝɾən?"

"And how can you be so certain?"

eɪvinhə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɪʃt tə ɹɪtɝn oʊnli saɪləns tə ðət kwɛstʃən, pæsɪŋ ðə lifləs bɹʌʃ θɪkəts ən ɡɪvɪŋ æmɪz noʊ ænsɝ. bʌt ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ən əpɹɛntəs, ən waɪl ʃi kəd nɑt bi fɔɹs tə spik, ʃi nu ðəɾ æmɪz wəd kip pʊʃɪŋ əntɪl ði ænsɝ keɪm aʊt. eɪvinhə hoʊpt ʃi wəd nɑɾ ɪnkɝ tu mʌtʃ toʊ baɪ hɝ ɹɪspɑns.

Aviendha hesitated. Part of her wished to return only silence to that question, passing the leafless brush thickets and giving Amys no answer. But she was just an apprentice, and while she could not be forced to speak, she knew that Amys would keep pushing until the answer came out. Aviendha hoped she would not incur too much toh by her response.

"ju noʊ ʌv ðə wʊmən mɪnz vjuɪŋz?" eɪvinhə sɛd.

"You know of the woman Min's viewings?" Aviendha said.

æmɪz nɑɾəd.

Amys nodded.

"wʌn ə ðoʊz vjuɪŋz ɹɪleɪts tə ɹænd ælθɹ ən ðə θɹi wɪmən hɪl lʌv. ənʌðɝ ɹɪleɪts tə maɪ tʃɪlʒɹən baɪ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn."

"One of those viewings relates to Rand al'Thor and the three women he will love. Another relates to my children by the Car'a'carn."

ʃi sɛd noʊ mɔɹ, ən æmɪz pɹɛs noʊ mɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf. boʊθ nu ðət wʌn wəd sunɝ faɪn ə stoʊn dɔɡ hu wəd ɹitʃɹit ðən faɪn ə vjuɪŋ ə mɪnz ðət wɛn ɹɔŋ.

She said no more, and Amys pressed no more. It was enough. Both knew that one would sooner find a Stone Dog who would retreat than find a viewing of Min's that went wrong.

ɑn wʌn hænd, ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə noʊ ðət ɹænd ælθɹ wəd bi hɝz, ɔlðoʊ ʃi wəɾ əv tə ʃɛɹ hɪm. ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪɡɹʌdʒ ɪleɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt mɪn . . . wɛl, eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt ɹɪli noʊ hɝ. ɹəɡɑɹdləs, ðə vjuɪŋ wɑz ə kʌmfɝt. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ bɑðɝsəm. eɪvinhə lʌvd ɹænd ælθɹ kəz ʃi tʃoʊz tə, nɑt kəz ʃi wɑz dɛstɪn tə. ʌv kɔɹs, mɪnz vjuɪŋ dɪdnt ɡɛɹənti ðəɾ eɪvinhə wəɾ æktʃəli  bi eɪbəl tə mɛɹi ɹænd, soʊ pɝhæps ʃi hæd mɪsspoʊkən tə æmɪz. jɛs, hi wəd lʌv θɹi wɪmən ən θɹi wɪmən wəd lʌv hɪm, bʌt wəɾ eɪvinhə faɪn ə weɪ tə mɛɹi hɪm?

On one hand, it was good to know that Rand al'Thor would be hers, although she would have to share him. She did not begrudge Elayne, of course, but Min . . . well, Aviendha did not really know her. Regardless, the viewing was a comfort. But it was also bothersome. Aviendha loved Rand al'Thor because she chose to, not because she was destined to. Of course, Min's viewing didn't guarantee that Aviendha would actually be able to marry Rand, so perhaps she had misspoken to Amys. Yes, he would love three women and three women would love him, but would Aviendha find a way to marry him?

noʊ, ðə fjutʃɝ wɑz nɑt sɝɾən, ən fəɹ səm ɹizən ðət bɹɔɾ əɹ kʌmfɝt. pɝhæps ʃi ʃəɾ əv wɝid, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt. ʃi wəd ɡɛɾ əɹ ɑnɝ bæk, ən ðən ʃi wəd mɛɹi ɹænd ælθɹ.

No, the future was not certain, and for some reason that brought her comfort. Perhaps she should have worried, but she did not. She would get her honor back, and then she would marry Rand al'Thor.

pɝhæps i wəd daɪ sun æftɝ, bʌt pɝhæps ən æmbʊʃ wəd kʌm ən ʃi wəd fɔl tə ən æɹoʊ ðɪs deɪ. wɝiɪŋ sɑlv nʌθɪŋ.

Perhaps he would die soon after, but perhaps an ambush would come and she would fall to an arrow this day. Worrying solved nothing.

toʊ, haʊɛvɝ, wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ.

Toh, however, was another matter.

"aɪ mɪsspoʊk, waɪz wʌn," eɪvinhə sɛd. "aɪ ɪmplaɪd ðət ðə vjuɪŋ sɛɾ aɪ wəd mɛɹi ɹænd ælθɹ. ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu. ɔl θɹi ʌv əs wɪl lʌv hɪm, ən waɪl ðəɾ ɪmplaɪz mɛɹɪdʒ, aɪ də nɑt noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən."

"I misspoke, Wise One," Aviendha said. "I implied that the viewing said I would marry Rand al'Thor. That is not true. All three of us will love him, and while that implies marriage, I do not know for certain."

æmɪz nɑɾəd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ toʊ; eɪvinhə hæd kɝɛktəd hɝsɛlf kwɪkli ɪnʌf. ðət wɑz wɛl.

Amys nodded. There was no toh; Aviendha had corrected herself quickly enough. That was well.

ʃi wəd nɑɾ æd mɔɹ ʃeɪm ɑn tɑp ʌv wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɝnd.

She would not add more shame on top of what she had already earned.

"vɛɹi wɛl, ðɛn," æmɪz sɛd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə pæθ əhɛɾ ə hɝ. "lɛɾ əs dɪskʌs tədeɪz pʌnɪʃmənt."

"Very well, then," Amys said, watching the path ahead of her. "Let us discuss today's punishment."

eɪvinhə ɹɪlækst slaɪtli. soʊ ʃi stɪl hæd taɪm tə dɪskʌvɝ wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn ɹɔŋ. wɛtləndɝz ɔfən sim kənfjuz baɪ il weɪz wɪð pʌnɪʃmənt, bʌt wɛtləndɝz hæd lɪɾəl ʌndɝstændɪŋ ʌv ɑnɝ. ɑnɝ dɪdn kʌm fɹəm biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt, bʌɾ æksɛptɪŋ ə pʌnɪʃmən ən bɛɹɪŋ ɪt ɹɪstɔɹɾ ɑnɝ. ðət wɑz ðə soʊl ə toʊ - ðə wɪlɪŋ loʊɝɪŋ ʌv wʌnsɛlf ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ðət wɪtʃ hæd bɪn lɔst. ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ tə hɝ ðət wɛtləndɝz kʊdn si ðɪs; ɪndid, ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət ðeɪ dɪdn fɑloʊ dʒiɾoʊ ɪnstɪŋktɪvli. wʌt wɑz laɪf wɪθaʊɾ ɑnɝ?

Aviendha relaxed slightly. So she still had time to discover what she had done wrong. Wetlanders often seemed confused by Aiel ways with punishment, but wetlanders had little understanding of honor. Honor didn't come from being punished, but accepting a punishment and bearing it restored honor. That was the soul of toh - the willing lowering of oneself in order to recover that which had been lost. It was strange to her that wetlanders couldn't see this; indeed, it was strange that they didn't follow ji'e'toh instinctively. What was life without honor?

æmɪz, ɹaɪtli, wʊdn tɛl eɪvinhə wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn ɹɔŋ. haʊɛvɝ, ʃi wɑz hævɪŋ noʊ səksɛs θɪŋkɪŋ θɹu ði ænsɝ ɑn əɹ oʊn, ən ɪt wəd kɑz lɛs ʃeɪm ɪf ʃi dɪskʌvɝd ði ænsɝ θɹu kɑnvɝseɪʃən. "jɛs," eɪvinhə sɛd kɛɹfəli. "aɪ ʃəd bi pʌnɪʃt. maɪ taɪm ɪn keɪɛmlɪn θɹɛɾənd tə meɪk mi wik."

Amys, rightly, wouldn't tell Aviendha what she had done wrong. However, she was having no success thinking through the answer on her own, and it would cause less shame if she discovered the answer through conversation. "Yes," Aviendha said carefully. "I should be punished. My time in Caemlyn threatened to make me weak."

æmɪz snɪft. "ju ɑɹ noʊ mɔɹ wik ðən jə wɝ wən jə kæɹid ðə spɪɹz, ɡɝl. ə fɛɹ bɪt stʃɹɔŋɝ, aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk. jəɹ taɪm wɪð jəɹ fɝst-sɪstɝ wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt fəɹ ju."

Amys sniffed. "You are no more weak than you were when you carried the spears, girl. A fair bit stronger, I should think. Your time with your first-sister was important for you."

soʊ ðət wɑzn ɪt. wən dɔɹinhə ən neɪdɪɹ hæd kʌm fəɹ hɝ, ðeɪ hæd sɛd ʃi niɾəd tə kəntɪnju hɝ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ əz ən əpɹɛntəs. jɛɾ ɪn ðə taɪm sɪns ði il hæd dɪpɑɹɾəd fəɹ ɑɹæd dumən, eɪvinhə hæd bɪn ɡɪvən noʊ lɛsənz. ʃi hæd bɪn əsaɪn tə kæɹi wɔɾɝ, tə mɛnd ʃɔlz, ən tə sɝv ti. ʃi hæd bɪn ɡɪvən ɔl mænɝ ə pʌnɪʃməns wɪð lɪɾəl ɛkspləneɪʃən ʌv wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn ɹɔŋ. ən wən ʃi dɪd sʌmθɪŋ ɑbviəs - laɪk ɡoʊɪŋ skaʊɾɪŋ wən ʃi ʃʊdn əv - ðə sɪvɛɹɪɾi ʌv əɹ pʌnɪʃmənt wɑz ɔlweɪz ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ði ɪnfɹækʃən ʃəɾ əv mɛɹɪɾɪd.

So that wasn't it. When Dorindha and Nadere had come for her, they had said she needed to continue her training as an apprentice. Yet in the time since the Aiel had departed for Arad Doman, Aviendha had been given no lessons. She had been assigned to carry water, to mend shawls, and to serve tea. She had been given all manner of punishments with little explanation of what she had done wrong. And when she did something obvious - like going scouting when she shouldn't have - the severity of her punishment was always greater than the infraction should have merited.

ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðə pʌnɪʃmənt wɑz ðə θɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz wɑntəɾ əɹ tə lɝn, bʌt ðət kəd nɑt bi. ʃi wɑz nɑt səm wɛtləndɝ u niɾəd tə bi tɔt ðə weɪz ʌv ɑnɝ. wʌt ɡʊd wəd kɑnstən ən ʌnɪkspleɪn pʌnɪʃmən du, ʌðɝ ðən tə wɔɹn ə səm ɡɹeɪv mɪsteɪk ʃi hæd meɪd?

It was almost as if the punishment was the thing the Wise Ones wanted her to learn, but that could not be. She was not some wetlander who needed to be taught the ways of honor. What good would constant and unexplained punishment do, other than to warn of some grave mistake she had made?

æmɪz ɹitʃt tə hɝ saɪd, əntiɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ hæŋɪŋ əɾ əɹ weɪst. ðə wʊlən bæɡ ʃi hɛld ʌp wɑz əbaʊt ðə saɪz ʌv ə fɪst. "wi hæv dɪsaɪɾɪd," ʃi sɛd, "ðæt wɪv bɪn tu læks ɪn əɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən. taɪm ɪz pɹɛʃəs ən wɪv noʊ ɹum lɛft fəɹ dɛləkəsi."

Amys reached to her side, untying something hanging at her waist. The woolen bag she held up was about the size of a fist. "We have decided," she said, "that we have been too lax in our instruction. Time is precious and we have no room left for delicacy."

eɪvinhə kʌvɝɾ əɹ sɝpɹaɪz. ðɛɹ pɹiviəs pʌnɪʃməns wɝ dɛləkət?

Aviendha covered her surprise. Their previous punishments were delicate?

"ðɛɹfɔɹ," æmɪz sɛd, hændɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə smɔl sæk, "ju wɪl teɪk ðɪs. ɪnsaɪɾ ɑɹ sidz. səm ɑɹ blæk, ʌðɝz ɑɹ bɹaʊn, ʌðɝz ɑɹ waɪt. ðɪs ivnɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ wi slip, jəl sɛpɝeɪt ðə kʌlɝz, ðən kaʊn haʊ mɛni ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌv itʃ wʌn. ɪf jə ɑɹ ɹɔŋ, wɪl mɪks əm təɡɛðɝ ən jəl stɑɹɾ əɡɛn."

"Therefore," Amys said, handing over the small sack, "you will take this. Inside are seeds. Some are black, others are brown, others are white. This evening, before we sleep, you will separate the colors, then count how many there are of each one. If you are wrong, we will mix them together and you will start again."

eɪvinhə faʊn hɝsɛlf ɡeɪpɪŋ, ən ʃi nɪɹli stʌmbəl tə ə stɑp. hɔlɪŋ wɔɾɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi wɝk. mɛndɪŋ kloʊðɪŋ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi wɝk. kʊkɪŋ milz wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɝk, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən noʊ ɡeɪʃeɪn hæd bɪn bɹɔt wɪð ðə smɔl ədvæns ɡɹup.

Aviendha found herself gaping, and she nearly stumbled to a stop. Hauling water was necessary work. Mending clothing was necessary work. Cooking meals was important work, particularly when no gai'shain had been brought with the small advance group.

bʌt ðɪs . . . ðɪs wɑz jusləs wɝk! ɪt wɑz nɑɾ oʊnli ənɪmpɔɹɾənt, ɪt wɑz fɹɪvələs. ɪt wɑz ðə kaɪndə pʌnɪʃmən ɹɪzɝv fəɹ oʊnli ðə moʊst stʌbɝn, əɹ moʊst ʃeɪmfəl, ʌv pipəl. ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst . . . ɔlmoʊs fɛlt əz ðoʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ kɔlɪŋ əɹ dætsæŋ!

But this . . . this was useless work! It was not only unimportant, it was frivolous. It was the kind of punishment reserved for only the most stubborn, or most shameful, of people. It almost . . . almost felt as though the Wise Ones were calling her da'tsang!

"baɪ saɪtblɪndɝz aɪz," ʃi wɪspɝɾ əz ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə kip ɹʌnɪŋ. "wʌt dɪɾ aɪ du?"

"By Sightblinder's eyes," she whispered as she forced herself to keep running. "What did I do?"

æmɪz ɡlænst ət hɝ, ən eɪvinhə lʊkt əweɪ. boʊθ nu ðət ʃi dɪdnt wɑn ən ænsɝ tə ðət kwɛstʃən. ʃi tʊk ðə bæɡ saɪlənli. ɪt wɑz ðə moʊs hjumɪlieɪɾɪŋ pʌnɪʃmənt ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ɡɪvən.

Amys glanced at her, and Aviendha looked away. Both knew that she didn't want an answer to that question. She took the bag silently. It was the most humiliating punishment she had ever been given.

æmɪz muvd ɔf tə ɹʌn wɪð ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz. eɪvinhə ʃʊk ɔf əɹ stupɝ, hɝ dɪtɝməneɪʃən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. hɝ mɪsteɪk mʌst əv bɪn mɔɹ pɹoʊfaʊn ðən ʃi hæd θɔt. æmɪz'

Amys moved off to run with the other Wise Ones. Aviendha shook off her stupor, her determination returning. Her mistake must have been more profound than she had thought. Amys'

pʌnɪʃmənt wɑz ən ɪndəkeɪʃən ə ðæt, ə hɪnt.

punishment was an indication of that, a hint.

ʃi oʊpən ðə bæɡ ən ɡlænst ɪnsaɪd. ðəɹ wɝ θɹi lɪɾəl ɛmpti ælɡoʊd bæɡz ɪnsaɪd tə hɛlp wɪð ðə sɛpɝeɪʃən, ən θaʊzənz ə taɪni sidz nɪɹli ɪnɡʌlf ðɛm. ðɪs pʌnɪʃmənt wɑz mɛn tə bi sin, mɛn tə bɹɪŋ əɹ ʃeɪm. wʌtɛvɝ ʃid dʌn, ɪt wɑz əfɛnsɪv nɑt dʒʌs tə ðə waɪz wʌnz, bʌt tə ɔl ɝaʊn hɝ, ivən ɪf ðeɪ - laɪk eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf - wɝ ɪɡnɝən ʌv ɪt.

She opened the bag and glanced inside. There were three little empty algode bags inside to help with the separation, and thousands of tiny seeds nearly engulfed them. This punishment was meant to be seen, meant to bring her shame. Whatever she'd done, it was offensive not just to the Wise Ones, but to all around her, even if they - like Aviendha herself - were ignorant of it.

ðəɾ oʊnli mɛnt ʃi hæd tə bi mɔɹ dɪtɝmənd.

That only meant she had to be more determined.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹ

CHAPTER 4

naɪtfɔl ɡɔɪn wɑtʃt ðə sʌn bɝn ðə klaʊdz tə dɛθ ɪn ðə wɛst, ðə faɪnəl laɪt feɪɾɪŋ. ðət heɪz ə pɝpɛtʃuəl ɡlum kɛp ðə sʌn ɪtsɛlf ʃɹaʊɾɪd. dʒʌst əz ɪt hɪd ðə stɑɹz fɹəm ɪz saɪɾ ət naɪt. tədeɪ ðə klaʊdz wɝ ənnətʃɝəli haɪ ɪn ði ɛɹ. ɔfən, dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊns tɪp wəd bi hɪɾən ɑn klaʊɾi deɪz, bʌt ðɪs θɪk, ɡɹeɪ heɪz hʌvɝd haɪ ɪnʌf ðət moʊst ə ðə taɪm, ɪt bɛɹli bɹʌʃt ðə maʊntənz dʒæɡd, bɹoʊkən tɪp.

Nightfall Gawyn watched the sun burn the clouds to death in the west, the final light fading. That haze of perpetual gloom kept the sun itself shrouded. Just as it hid the stars from his sight at night. Today the clouds were unnaturally high in the air. Often, Dragonmount's tip would be hidden on cloudy days, but this thick, gray haze hovered high enough that most of the time, it barely brushed the mountain's jagged, broken tip.

"lɛts ɛnɡeɪdʒ ðɛm," dʒɪsaʊ wɪspɝd fɹəm wɛɹ i kɹaʊtʃt bɪsaɪd ɡɔɪn ɑn ðə hɪltɑp.

"Let's engage them," Jisao whispered from where he crouched beside Gawyn on the hilltop.

ɡɔɪn ɡlænst əweɪ fɹəm ðə sʌnsɛt, bæk təwɔɹd ðə smɔl vɪlədʒ bɪloʊ. ɪt ʃʊɾə bɪn stɪl, seɪv pɝhæps fəɹ ə ɡʊdmən tʃɛkɪŋ ɑn ɪz laɪvstɑk wʌn læs taɪm bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ ɪn. ɪt ʃʊɾə bɪn dɪm, ənlɪt seɪv fəɹ ə fju tæloʊ kændəlz bɝnɪŋ ɪn wɪndoʊz əz pipəl fɪnɪʃt ivnɪŋ milz.

Gawyn glanced away from the sunset, back toward the small village below. It should have been still, save perhaps for a goodman checking on his livestock one last time before turning in. It should have been dim, unlit save for a few tallow candles burning in windows as people finished evening meals.

bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt dɪm. ɪt wɑz nɑt kwaɪət. ðə vɪlədʒ wɑz əlaɪt wɪð æŋɡɹi tɔɹtʃɪz kæɹid baɪ ə dʌzən stɝɾi fɪɡjɝz. baɪ ðət tɔɹtʃlaɪɾ ən ðə laɪɾ ə ðə daɪɪŋ sʌn, ɡɔɪn kəd meɪk aʊt ðəɾ itʃ wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə nɑndɪskɹɪp junəfɔɹm ə bɹaʊn ən blæk. ɡɔɪn kʊdn si ðə θɹi-stɑɹɾ ɪnsɪɡniə ɑn ðɛɹ junəfɔɹmz, bʌɾ i nu ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ.

But it was not dim. It was not quiet. The village was alight with angry torches carried by a dozen sturdy figures. By that torchlight and the light of the dying sun, Gawyn could make out that each was wearing a nondescript uniform of brown and black. Gawyn couldn't see the three-starred insignia on their uniforms, but he knew it was there.

fɹəm ɪz dɪstən væntədʒ, ɡɔɪn wɑtʃt ə fju lɑtɛkəmɝz stʌmbəl fɹəm ðɛɹ hoʊmz, lʊkɪŋ fɹaɪɾənd ən wɝiɾ əz ðeɪ ɡæðɝd wɪð ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə kɹaʊɾəd skwɛɹ. ðiz vɪlɪdʒɝz wɛlkəm ði ɑɹm fɔɹs wɪð ɹɪlʌktəns. wɪmən klʌtʃt tʃɪlʒɹən, mɛn wɝ kɛɹfəl tə kip ðɛɹ aɪz daʊnkæst. "wi doʊnt wɑn tʃɹʌbəl," ðə pɑstʃɝz sɛd. ðeɪɾ əndaʊɾɪdli hɝd fɹəm ʌðɝ vɪlədʒəz ðət ðiz ɪnveɪɾɝz wɝ ɔɹɾɝli. ðə soʊlʒɝz peɪd fəɹ ɡʊdz ðeɪ tʊk, ən noʊ jʌŋ mɛn wɝ pɹɛst ɪndə sɝvəs - ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝn tɝn əweɪ iðɝ. ə vɛɹi ɑɾ ɪnveɪɾɪŋ ɑɹmi ɪndid. haʊɛvɝ, ɡɔɪn nu wʌt ðə pipəl wəd θɪŋk. ðɪs ɑɹmi wɑz lɛd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən u kəd seɪ wʌt wɑz ɑɾ əɹ nɔɹməl wən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɪnvɑlvd?

From his distant vantage, Gawyn watched a few latecomers stumble from their homes, looking frightened and worried as they gathered with the others in the crowded square. These villagers welcomed the armed force with reluctance. Women clutched children, men were careful to keep their eyes downcast. "We don't want trouble," the postures said. They'd undoubtedly heard from other villages that these invaders were orderly. The soldiers paid for goods they took, and no young men were pressed into service - though they weren't turned away either. A very odd invading army indeed. However, Gawyn knew what the people would think. This army was led by Aes Sedai, and who could say what was odd or normal when Aes Sedai were involved?

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sɪstɝz wɪð ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ pətʃɹoʊl, θæŋk ðə laɪt. ðə soʊlʒɝz, pəlaɪt bʌt stɝn, laɪn ʌp ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz ən lʊkt əm oʊvɝ. ðən ə pɛɹ ə soʊlʒɝz ɛntɝɾ itʃ haʊs ən bɑɹn, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ɪt. nʌθɪŋ wɑz teɪkən ən nʌθɪŋ wɑz bɹoʊkən. ɔl vɛɹi niɾ ən kɔɹdʒəl. ɡɔɪn kəɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ ði ɔfəsɝ ɔfɝɪŋ əpɑlədʒiz tə ðə vɪlədʒ meɪɝ.

There were no sisters with this particular patrol, thank the Light. The soldiers, polite but stern, lined up the villagers and looked them over. Then a pair of soldiers entered each house and barn, inspecting it. Nothing was taken and nothing was broken. All very neat and cordial. Gawyn could almost hear the officer offering apologies to the village mayor.

"ɡɔɪn?" dʒɪsaʊ æskt. "aɪ kaʊn bɛɹli ə dʌzən ə ðɛm. ɪf wi sɛn ɹɑɾɪks skwɑd tə kʌm ɪn fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ, wɪl kʌɾ ɔf boʊθ saɪdz ən smæʃ əm bɪtwin ʌs. ɪts ɡɛɾɪŋ dɑɹk ɪnʌf ðət ðeɪ woʊn si əs kʌmɪŋ. wi kəd teɪk əm wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp ə læðɝ."

"Gawyn?" Jisao asked. "I count barely a dozen of them. If we send Rodic's squad to come in from the north, we'll cut off both sides and smash them between us. It's getting dark enough that they won't see us coming. We could take them without so much as running up a lather."

"æn ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz?" ɡɔɪn æskt. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ tʃɪlʒɹən daʊn ðɛɹ."

"And the villagers?" Gawyn asked. "There are children down there."

"ðæt hæzən stɑpt əs ʌðɝ taɪmz."

"That hasn't stopped us other times."

"ðoʊz taɪmz wɝ dɪfɹənt," ɡɔɪn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "ðə læs θɹi vɪlədʒəz ðeɪv sɝtʃt pɔɪn ə dɝɛk laɪn təwɔɹd dɔɹlən. ɪf ðɪs ɡɹup vænɪʃɪz, ðə nɛkst wʌn wɪl wʌndɝ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðeɪ nɪɹli ənkʌvɝd. wid dʒɹɔ ði ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmiz aɪ ɪn ðɪs dɝɛkʃən."

"Those times were different," Gawyn said, shaking his head. "The last three villages they've searched point a direct line toward Dorlan. If this group vanishes, the next one will wonder what it was they nearly uncovered. We'd draw the entire army's eye in this direction."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"noʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛd sɔfli. "wi hæv tə noʊ wən tə fɔl bæk, dʒɪsaʊ."

"No," Gawyn said softly. "We have to know when to fall back, Jisao."

"soʊ wi keɪm ɔl ðɪs weɪ fəɹ nʌθɪŋ."

"So we came all this way for nothing."

"wi keɪm ɔl ðɪs weɪ fəɹ ən ɑpɝtunəɾi," ɡɔɪn sɛd, bækɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɪltɑp, meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən i dɪdnt ʃoʊ ə pɹoʊfaɪl ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən. "ænd naʊ ðəɾ aɪv ɪnspɛktɪd ðəɾ ɑpɝtunəɾi, wɝ nɑt gɑnə teɪk ɪt. oʊnli ə ful lusɪz ɪz æɹoʊ dʒʌs kəz hiz ɡɑɾ ə bɝɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm."

"We came all this way for an opportunity," Gawyn said, backing away from the hilltop, making certain he didn't show a profile on the horizon. "And now that I've inspected that opportunity, we're not going to take it. Only a fool looses his arrow just because he's got a bird in front of him."

"waɪ wʊdn jə lus ɪɾ ɪf ɪts ɹaɪt ðəɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ju?" dʒɪsaʊ æskt əz i dʒɔɪnd ɡɔɪn.

"Why wouldn't you loose it if it's right there in front of you?" Jisao asked as he joined Gawyn.

"bɪkɔz səmtaɪmz ðə pɹaɪz ɪzənt wɝθ ði æɹoʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "kʌm ɑn."

"Because sometimes the prize isn't worth the arrow," Gawyn said. "Come on."

bɪloʊ, weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wɪð læntɝnz hʊɾɪd, wɝ səm ə ðə vɛɹi mɛn ðə soʊlʒɝz ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ wɝ sɝtʃɪŋ fɔɹ. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn mʌst əv bɪn vɛɹi dɪspliz tə lɝn ðəɹ wɑz ə hæɹiɪŋ fɔɹs haɪɾɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ nɪɹbaɪ. hid bɪn dɪlɪdʒən ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə flʌʃ ɪɾ aʊt, bʌt ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd nɪɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn wɑz lɪbɝəli spɹɪŋkəld wɪð vɪlədʒəz, fɔɹəsts ən sɪkluɾɪd væliz ðət kəd haɪɾ ə smɔl, moʊbəl stʃɹaɪk fɔɹs. soʊ fɑɹ, ɡɔɪn hæd mænədʒ tə kip ɪz jʌŋɡəlɪŋz aʊɾ ə saɪt waɪl pʊlɪŋ ɔf ði əkeɪʒənəl ɹeɪɾ əɹ æmbʊʃ ɑn bɹaɪnz fɔɹsɪz. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli soʊ mʌtʃ jə kəd də wɪð θɹi hʌnʒɹəd mɛn, haʊɛvɝ. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən jə feɪst wʌn ə ðə faɪv ɡɹeɪt kæptənz.

Below, waiting in the dark with lanterns hooded, were some of the very men the soldiers in the village were searching for. Gareth Bryne must have been very displeased to learn there was a harrying force hiding somewhere nearby. He'd been diligent in trying to flush it out, but the countryside near Tar Valon was liberally sprinkled with villages, forests and secluded valleys that could hide a small, mobile strike force. So far, Gawyn had managed to keep his Younglings out of sight while pulling off the occasional raid or ambush on Bryne's forces. There was only so much you could do with three hundred men, however. Particularly when you faced one of the five Great Captains.

æm aɪ dɛstɪn tə ɛn ʌp faɪɾɪŋ əɡɛnst itʃ ən ɛvɹi mæn u hæz bɪn ə mɛntɔɹ tə mi?

Am I destined to end up fighting against each and every man who has been a mentor to me?

ɡɔɪn tʊk ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɪz hɔɹs ən ɡeɪv ə saɪlən ɔɹɾɝ tə wɪðdʒɹɔ baɪ ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz ɹaɪt hænd, ðən dʒɛstʃɝd ʃɑɹpli əweɪ fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒ. ðə mɛn muvd wɪθaʊt kɑmɛnt, dɪsmaʊntɪŋ ən liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ maʊns fəɹ boʊθ stɛlθ ən seɪfti.

Gawyn took the reins of his horse and gave a silent order to withdraw by raising his right hand, then gestured sharply away from the village. The men moved without comment, dismounting and leading their mounts for both stealth and safety.

ɡɔɪn hæd θɔɾ i wɑz oʊvɝ hæmɝ ən kaʊulænz dɛθs; bɹaɪn hɪmsɛlf hæd tɔt ɡɔɪn ðət ðə bæɾəlfild səmtaɪmz meɪɾ ælaɪz ɪndə sʌɾən foʊz. ɡɔɪn hæd fɔɾ ɪz fɔɹmɝ titʃɝz, ən ɡɔɪn hæd wʌn. ðət wɑz ði ɛn ʌv ɪt.

Gawyn had thought he was over Hammar and Coulin's deaths; Bryne himself had taught Gawyn that the battlefield sometimes made allies into sudden foes. Gawyn had fought his former teachers, and Gawyn had won. That was the end of it.

ɹisənli, haʊɛvɝ, hɪz maɪn sim dɪtɝmən tə dʒɹɛdʒ ʌp ðoʊz kɔɹpsəz ən kæɹi ðɛm əbaʊt.

Recently, however, his mind seemed determined to dredge up those corpses and carry them about.

waɪ naʊ, æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ?

Why now, after so long?

hi səspɛktəɾ ɪz sɛns ʌv ɡɪl hæd tə də wɪð feɪsɪŋ bɹaɪn, hɪz fɝst ən moʊst ɪnfluɛntʃəl ɪnstʃɹʌktɝ ɪn ði ɑɹts ʌv wɔɹ. ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz i ɡaɪɾəd tʃælənʒ əkɹɔs ðə dɑɹkənɪŋ lændskeɪp; hi kɛpt ɪz mɛn əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹoʊɾ ɪn keɪs bɹaɪnz skaʊts hæd pleɪst wɑtʃɝz. ðə fɪfti mɛn ɝaʊnd ɡɔɪn wɔkt əz kwaɪətli əz pɑsəbəl, ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊfbits dɛɾənd baɪ ðə spɹɪŋi ɝθ.

He suspected his sense of guilt had to do with facing Bryne, his first and most influential instructor in the arts of war. Gawyn shook his head as he guided Challenge across the darkening landscape; he kept his men away from the road in case Bryne's scouts had placed watchers. The fifty men around Gawyn walked as quietly as possible, the horses' hoofbeats deadened by the springy earth.

ɪf bɹaɪn hæd bɪn ʃɑk tə dɪskʌvɝ ə hæɹiɪŋ fɔɹs stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əɾ ɪz aʊtʃɹaɪɾɝz, ðən ɡɔɪn hæd bɪn ikwəli ʃɑk tə dɪskʌvɝ ðoʊz θɹi stɑɹz ɑn ðə junəfɔɹmz ə ðə mɛn i slu. haʊ hæd ðə waɪt taʊɝz ɛnəmiz ɹɪkɹuɾɪd ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst mɪlətɛɹi maɪn ɪn ɔl ʌv ændɝ? ən wʌt wɑz ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd duɪŋ faɪɾɪŋ wɪð ə ɡɹup ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɛbəlz ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs? hi ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn pɹətɛktɪŋ ɪleɪn.

If Bryne had been shocked to discover a harrying force striking at his outriders, then Gawyn had been equally shocked to discover those three stars on the uniforms of the men he slew. How had the White Tower's enemies recruited the greatest military mind in all of Andor? And what was the Captain-General of the Queen's Guard doing fighting with a group of Aes Sedai rebels in the first place? He should have been in Caemlyn protecting Elayne.

laɪt sɛn ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæɾ ɝaɪvd ɪn ændɝ. ʃi kʊdn stɪl bi wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz. nɑt wɪð əɹ hoʊmlæn lækɪŋ ə kwin. hɝ duɾi tə ændɝ aʊtweɪɾ əɹ duɾi tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Light send that Elayne had arrived in Andor. She couldn't still be with the rebels. Not with her homeland lacking a queen. Her duty to Andor outweighed her duty to the White Tower.

ən wʌɾ ə jəɹ duɾi, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd? hi θɔt tə hɪmsɛlf.

And what of your duty, Gawyn Trakand? he thought to himself.

hi wɑzn sɝɾən i hæd duɾi, əɹ ɑnɝ, lɛf tə hɪm. pɝhæps ɪz ɡɪlt əbaʊt hæmɝ, hɪz naɪtmɛɹz ʌv wɔɹ ən dɛθ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, wɝ du tə ðə sloʊ ɹiləzeɪʃən ðəɾ i maɪɾ əv ɡɪvən ɪz əlidʒəns tə ðə ɹɔŋ saɪd. hɪz lɔɪəlti bɪlɔŋ tə ɪleɪn ən ɛɡwin. wʌt, ðɛn, wɑz i stɪl duɪŋ faɪɾɪŋ ə bæɾəl i dɪdn kɛɹ əbaʊt, hɛlpɪŋ ə saɪd ðət - baɪ ɔl əkaʊns - wɑz əpoʊz tə ðə wʌn ɪleɪn ən ɛɡwin hæd tʃoʊzən?

He wasn't certain he had duty, or honor, left to him. Perhaps his guilt about Hammar, his nightmares of war and death at Dumai's Wells, were due to the slow realization that he might have given his allegiance to the wrong side. His loyalty belonged to Elayne and Egwene. What, then, was he still doing fighting a battle he didn't care about, helping a side that - by all accounts - was opposed to the one Elayne and Egwene had chosen?

ðəɹ dʒʌst æksɛptɪd, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. ɪleɪn ən ɛɡwin dɪdn tʃuz ðɪs saɪd - ðeɪ ɑɹ dʒʌs duɪŋ wʌt ðeɪv bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə du! bʌt ðə θɪŋz ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd sɛd tə hɪm ɔl ðoʊz mʌnθs əɡoʊ, bæk ɪn kɛɹhin, sədʒɛstəd ðət ʃi hæd meɪɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒən wɪlɪŋli.

They're just Accepted, he told himself. Elayne and Egwene didn't choose this side - they are just doing what they've been ordered to do! But the things that Egwene had said to him all those months ago, back in Cairhien, suggested that she had made her decision willingly.

ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən ə saɪd. hæmɝ hæd tʃoʊzən ə saɪd. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæd, əpɛɹənli, tʃoʊzən ə saɪd.

She had chosen a side. Hammar had chosen a side. Gareth Bryne had, apparently, chosen a side.

bʌt ɡɔɪn kəntɪnjud tə wɑnə bi ɑn boʊθ saɪdz. ðə dɪvɪʒən wɑz ɹɪpɪŋ ɪm əpɑɹt.

But Gawyn continued to want to be on both sides. The division was ripping him apart.

ən aʊɝ aʊɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ, ɡɔɪn ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ tə maʊn ən teɪk tə ðə ɹoʊd. hoʊpfəli, bɹaɪnz skaʊts wʊdn θɪŋk tə sɝtʃ ðə læn aʊtsaɪd ðə vɪlədʒ. ɪf ðeɪ dɪd, ðə tʃɹæks ə fɪfti hɔɹsmən wəd bi hɑɹd tə mɪs. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðæt. ðə bɛs θɪŋ naʊ wɑz tə ɹitʃ fɝm ɡɹaʊnd, wɛɹ ðə saɪnz ə ðɛɹ pæsɪŋ wəd bi hɪɾən baɪ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz ə fʊtfɔlz ən tʃɹæfɪk.

An hour out of the village, Gawyn gave the order to mount and take to the road. Hopefully, Bryne's scouts wouldn't think to search the land outside the village. If they did, the tracks of fifty horsemen would be hard to miss. There was no avoiding that. The best thing now was to reach firm ground, where the signs of their passing would be hidden by a thousand years of footfalls and traffic.

tu pɛɹz ə soʊlʒɝz ɹoʊɾ ɔf ɪn fɹʌn ən tu pɛɹz hʌŋ bæk tə wɑtʃ. ðə ɹɛs meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ saɪləns, ðoʊ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz naʊ paʊndɪɾ ə θʌndɝəs ɡæləp. nʌn æskt waɪ ðeɪ wɝ wɪθdʒɹɔɪŋ, bʌt ɡɔɪn nu ðət ðeɪ wɝ wʌndɝɪŋ, dʒʌst əz dʒɪsaʊ hæd.

Two pairs of soldiers rode off in front and two pairs hung back to watch. The rest maintained their silence, though their horses now pounded a thunderous gallop. None asked why they were withdrawing, but Gawyn knew that they were wondering, just as Jisao had.

ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊd mɛn. pɝhæps tu ɡʊd. əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd, ɹeɪjɹ pʊld ɪz maʊn ʌp bɪsaɪd ɡɔɪnz.

They were good men. Perhaps too good. As they rode, Rajar pulled his mount up beside Gawyn's.

dʒʌst ə fju mʌnθs əɡoʊ, ɹeɪjɹ hæd bɪn ə juθ. bʌt naʊ ɡɔɪn kʊdn θɪŋk ə hɪm əz ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ə soʊlʒɝ. ə vɛɾɝən. səm mɛn ɡeɪn ɪkspɪɹiəns θɹu jɪɹz spɛn lɪvɪŋ. ʌðɝ mɛn ɡeɪn ɪkspɪɹiəns θɹu mʌnθs spɛnt wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛɹ fɹɛnz daɪ.

Just a few months ago, Rajar had been a youth. But now Gawyn couldn't think of him as anything other than a soldier. A veteran. Some men gained experience through years spent living. Other men gained experience through months spent watching their friends die.

ɡlænsɪŋ ʌpwɝd, ɡɔɪn mɪs ðə stɑɹz. ðeɪ hɪd ðɛɹ feɪsəz fɹəm ɪm bɪhaɪn ðoʊz klaʊdz.

Glancing upward, Gawyn missed the stars. They hid their faces from him behind those clouds.

laɪk il bɪhaɪn blæk veɪlz. "wɛɹ dɪd wi ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ, ɹeɪjɹ?" ɡɔɪn æskt əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd.

Like Aiel behind black veils. "Where did we go wrong, Rajar?" Gawyn asked as they rode.

"ɹɔŋ, lɔɹd ɡɔɪn?" ɹeɪjɹ æskt. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðət wi dɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. wi kʊdn əv noʊn wɪtʃ vɪlədʒəz ðət pətʃɹoʊl wəd tʃuz tə ɪnspɛkt, əɹ ðət ðeɪ wʊdn tɝn əlɔŋ ði oʊld wæɡoʊnɹaɪt ɹoʊd, əz jə hæd hoʊpt. səm ə ðə mɛn meɪ bi kənfjuzd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɹaɪt tə wɪðdʒɹɔ."

"Wrong, Lord Gawyn?" Rajar asked. "I don't know that we did anything wrong. We couldn't have known which villages that patrol would choose to inspect, or that they wouldn't turn along the old Wagonright Road, as you had hoped. Some of the men may be confused, but it was right to withdraw."

"aɪ wɑzn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɹeɪd," ɡɔɪn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "aɪm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs hoʊl blʌɾi sɪtʃueɪʃən. jə ʃʊdn əv tə ɡoʊ ɑn səplaɪ ɹeɪdz əɹ spɛn jəɹ taɪm kɪlɪŋ skaʊts; jə ʃʊɾə bɪkʌm ə wɔɹɾɝ tə səm fɹɛʃli mɪntɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ baɪ naʊ." ən aɪ ʃəd bi bæk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, wɪð ɪleɪn.

"I wasn't talking about the raid," Gawyn said, shaking his head. "I'm talking about this whole bloody situation. You shouldn't have to go on supply raids or spend your time killing scouts; you should have become a Warder to some freshly minted Aes Sedai by now." And I should be back in Caemlyn, with Elayne.

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ mæn sɛd.

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," the shorter man said.

"wɛl, ɪt woʊv əs ɪndə ə hoʊl," ɡɔɪn mʌɾɝd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ wʌns əɡɛn. "æn ɪleɪɾə dʌzn sim tu iɡɝ tə pʊl əs aʊɾ ʌv ɪt."

"Well, it wove us into a hole," Gawyn muttered, glancing at the overcast sky once again. "And Elaida doesn't seem too eager to pull us out of it."

ɹeɪjɹ lʊkt ət ɡɔɪn ɹipɹoʊtʃfəli. "ðə waɪt taʊɝz mɛθədz ɑɹ ɪts oʊn, lɔɹd ɡɔɪn, ən soʊ ɑɹ ɪts moʊɾɪvz. ɪɾ ɪzən fəɹ əs tə kwɛstʃən. wʌt ɡʊɾ ɪz ə wɔɹɾɝ u kwɛstʃənz ði ɔɹɾɝz ə hɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ? ə ɡʊd weɪ tə ɡɛt boʊθ ə jə kɪld, ðəɾ ɪz."

Rajar looked at Gawyn reproachfully. "The White Tower's methods are its own, Lord Gawyn, and so are its motives. It isn't for us to question. What good is a Warder who questions the orders of his Aes Sedai? A good way to get both of you killed, that is."

jəɹ nɑɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ, ɹeɪjɹ. ðæts ðə pɹɑbləm! ɡɔɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ. nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ jʌŋɡəlɪŋz sim tə bi pleɪɡd wɪð ðiz kwɛstʃənz. tə ðɛm, ðə wɝld wɑz mʌtʃ sɪmpəlɝ. wʌn dɪɾ əz ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, kəmændəd. nɛvɝ maɪn ɪf ðoʊz kəmænz sim dɪzaɪn tə ɡɛt jə kɪld.

You're not a Warder, Rajar. That's the problem! Gawyn said nothing. None of the other Younglings seemed to be plagued with these questions. To them, the world was much simpler. One did as the White Tower, and the Amyrlin Seat, commanded. Never mind if those commands seemed designed to get you killed.

θɹi hʌnʒɹəd juðz əɡɛnst ə fɔɹs ʌv oʊvɝ fɪfti θaʊzən hɑɹɾənd soʊlʒɝz, kəmændəd baɪ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hɪmsɛlf? wɪl ə ði æmɪɝlɪn əɹ nɑt, ðət wɑz ə dɛθtʃɹæp. ði oʊnli ɹizən ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz hæd sɝvaɪvd əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ hæd wɑz kəz ʌv ɡɔɪnz fəmɪljɛɹəɾi wɪð ɪz titʃɝz weɪz. hi nu wɛɹ bɹaɪn wəd sɛn pətʃɹoʊlz ən aʊtʃɹaɪɾɪŋ skaʊts, ən nu haʊ tə ɪveɪɾ ɪz sɝtʃ pæɾɝnz.

Three hundred youths against a force of over fifty thousand hardened soldiers, commanded by Gareth Bryne himself? Will of the Amyrlin or not, that was a deathtrap. The only reason the Younglings had survived as long as they had was because of Gawyn's familiarity with his teacher's ways. He knew where Bryne would send patrols and outriding scouts, and knew how to evade his search patterns.

ɪt wɑz stɪl ə fjuɾəl ɛfɝt. ɡɔɪn dɪdn əv nɪɹli ðə tʃɹups niɾəd fəɹ ə tʃɹu hæɹiɪŋ fɔɹs, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wɪð bɹaɪn ɛntʃɹɛntʃt ɪn ɪz sidʒ. bɪɑn ðæt, ðəɹ wɑz ðə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl mæɾɝ ə ði ɑɹmiz kəmplit læk ʌv ə səplaɪ laɪn. haʊ wɝ ðeɪ ɡɛɾɪŋ fud? ðeɪ pɝtʃəst səplaɪz fɹəm ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ vɪlədʒəz, bʌt nɑt nɪɹli ɪnʌf tə fid ðɛmsɛlvz. haʊ kəd ðeɪ pɑsəbli hæv kæɹiɾ ɔl ðeɪ niɾəd waɪl stɪl muvɪŋ kwɪkli ɪnʌf tə əpɪɹ, wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ, ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv wɪntɝ?

It was still a futile effort. Gawyn didn't have nearly the troops needed for a true harrying force, particularly with Bryne entrenched in his siege. Beyond that, there was the remarkable matter of the army's complete lack of a supply line. How were they getting food? They purchased supplies from the surrounding villages, but not nearly enough to feed themselves. How could they possibly have carried all they needed while still moving quickly enough to appear, without warning, in the middle of winter?

ɡɔɪnz ətæks wɝ nɛks tə minɪŋləs. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə mæn θɪŋk ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn dʒʌst wɑntəd hɪm, ən ði ʌðɝ jʌŋɡəlɪŋz, aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. bɪfɔɹ dəməaɪz wɛlz, ɡɔɪn hæd səspɛktəd ðət wɑz ðə keɪs. naʊ hi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ sɝɾən. ən jɛt jə kəntɪnju tə fɑloʊ hɝ ɔɹɾɝz, hi θɔt tə hɪmsɛlf.

Gawyn's attacks were next to meaningless. It was enough to make a man think that the Amyrlin just wanted him, and the other Younglings, out of the way. Before Dumai's Wells, Gawyn had suspected that was the case. Now he was growing certain. And yet you continue to follow her orders, he thought to himself.

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. bɹaɪnz skaʊts wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ deɪnʒɝəsli kloʊs tə hɪz beɪs ʌv ɑpɝeɪʃənz, ən ɡɔɪn kʊdn ɹɪsk kɪlɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ ə ðɛm wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ hɪmsɛlf əweɪ. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə hɛd bæk tə dɔɹlən. pɝhæps ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðəɹ wəɾ əv ə sədʒɛstʃən ɑn haʊ tə pɹəsid.

He shook his head. Bryne's scouts were getting dangerously close to his base of operations, and Gawyn couldn't risk killing any more of them without giving himself away. It was time to head back to Dorlan. Perhaps the Aes Sedai there would have a suggestion on how to proceed.

hi hʌŋkɝd daʊn ɑn ɪz hɔɹs ən kəntɪnjud ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə naɪt. laɪt, aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd si ðə stɑɹz, hi θɔt.

He hunkered down on his horse and continued riding into the night. Light, I wish I could see the stars, he thought.

tʃæptɝ faɪv

CHAPTER 5

eɪ teɪl ə blʌd ɹænd kɹɔs ðə tʃɹæmpəl mænɝ ɡɹin, bænɝz flæpɪŋ bɪfɔɹ hɪm, tɛns sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪm, hɔɹsəz wɪniɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ pɪkəts ɑn ðə fɑɹ wɛst saɪd. ɪn ði ɛɹ hʌŋ ðə sɛns ʌv ən ɪfɪʃənt wɔɹ kæmp: smoʊk ən seɪvɝ fɹəm ðə stupəts wɝ mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ði əkeɪʒənəl wɪf ə hɔɹs dʌŋ əɹ ən ənwɑʃt bɑɾi.

A Tale of Blood Rand crossed the trampled manor green, banners flapping before him, tents surrounding him, horses whinnying in their pickets on the far west side. In the air hung the scents of an efficient war camp: smoke and savor from the stewpots were much stronger than the occasional whiff of horse dung or an unwashed body.

bæʃɪɹz mɛn meɪnteɪn ə taɪɾi kæmp, bʌsiɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð ðə hʌnʒɹədz ə lɪɾəl tæsks ðəɾ əlaʊd ði ɑɹmi tə fʌŋkʃən: ʃɑɹpənɪŋ sɔɹdz, ɔɪlɪŋ lɛðɝz, mɛndɪŋ sæɾəlz, fɛtʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə stʃɹim. səm pɹæktəs tʃɑɹdʒəz tə ðə lɛft, ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹin, ɪn ðə speɪs bɪtwin tɛn laɪnz ən ðə skɹæɡli tʃɹiz ɡɹoʊɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə stʃɹim. ðə mɛn hɛld ɡlimɪŋ lænsɪz ət ðə lɛvəl əz ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz tʃɹæmpəl ðə mʌɾi ɡɹaʊn ɪn ə lɔŋ swɑθ. ðə mənuvɝz nɑɾ oʊnli kɛp ðɛɹ skɪlz ʃɑɹp, bʌɾ ɛksɝsaɪz ðə hɔɹsəz əz wɛl.

Bashere's men maintained a tidy camp, busying themselves with the hundreds of little tasks that allowed the army to function: sharpening swords, oiling leathers, mending saddles, fetching water from the stream. Some practiced charges to the left, on the far side of the green, in the space between tent lines and the scraggly trees growing alongside the stream. The men held gleaming lances at the level as their horses trampled the muddy ground in a long swath. The maneuvers not only kept their skills sharp, but exercised the horses as well.

əz ɔlweɪz, ɹænd wɑz tʃɹeɪl baɪ ə flɑk ʌv ətɛndəns. meɪɾənz wɝ ɪz ɡɑɹdz, ən ði il wɑtʃt ðə sɑldəiən soʊlʒɝz wɪð wɛɹinɪs. bɪsaɪɾ ɪm wɝ sɛvɹəl ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ wɝ ɔlweɪz əbaʊt hɪm, naʊ. ðə pæɾɝn hæd noʊ pleɪs fəɹ ɪz wʌntaɪm ɪnsɪstəns ðəɾ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ bi kɛpt əɾ ɑɹmz lɛŋθ. ɪt woʊv əz ɪt wɪld, ən ɪkspɪɹiəns hæd ʃoʊn ðət ɹænd niɾəd ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ.

As always, Rand was trailed by a flock of attendants. Maidens were his guards, and the Aiel watched the Saldaean soldiers with wariness. Beside him were several Aes Sedai. They were always about him, now. The Pattern had no place for his onetime insistence that all Aes Sedai be kept at arm's length. It wove as it willed, and experience had shown that Rand needed these Aes Sedai.

wʌɾ i wɑntəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ mæɾɝd. hi ʌndɝstʊd ðət naʊ.

What he wanted no longer mattered. He understood that now.

ɪt wɑz lɪɾəl kʌmfɝt ðət mɛni ʌv ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ɪz kæmp hæd swɔɹn əlidʒəns tə hɪm.

It was little comfort that many of these Aes Sedai in his camp had sworn allegiance to him.

ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ fɑloʊd ðɛɹ oʊðz ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn weɪz, ən ðeɪ wəd dɪsaɪd wʌt ðɛɹ "fiəlti" tə hɪm wəd ɹikwaɪɝ.

Everyone knew that Aes Sedai followed their oaths in their own ways, and they would decide what their "fealty" to him would require.

ɛlzə pɛnfəl - hu əkʌmpəniɾ ɪm ðɪs deɪ - wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæd swɔɹn tə hɪm. ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, ʃi hæɾ ə feɪs ðət maɪt bi kənsɪɾɝd pɹɪɾi, ɪf wʌn dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ði eɪdʒləs kwɑləɾi ðət mɑɹkt əɹ əz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi wɑz plɛzənt, fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðət ʃi hæd hɛlp kɪdnæp ɹænd ən lɑk ɪm ɪn ə bɑks fəɹ deɪz, tə bi pʊld aʊɾ oʊnli fəɹ ði əkeɪʒənəl biɾɪŋ.

Elza Penfell - who accompanied him this day - was one of those who had sworn to him. Of the Green Ajah, she had a face that might be considered pretty, if one didn't recognize the ageless quality that marked her as Aes Sedai. She was pleasant, for an Aes Sedai, despite the fact that she had helped kidnap Rand and lock him in a box for days, to be pulled out only for the occasional beating.

ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd, luz θɝɪn ɡɹaʊld.

In the back of his mind, Lews Therin growled.

ðət wɑz pæst. ɛlzə hæd swɔɹn. ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə əlaʊ ɹænd tə juz hɝ. ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ətɛndɪŋ ɪm tədeɪ wɑz lɛs pɹɪdɪktəbəl; ʃi wɑz ə mɛmbɝ ə kædzueɪnz ɹɛɾənu. kɔɹəl hoʊviən -  ə slɪm jɛloʊ wɪð blu aɪz, waɪl dɑɹk hɛɹ, ən ə pɝpɛtʃuəl smaɪl - hæd swɔɹn noʊ oʊðz tə də əz i sɛd. dɪspaɪt ðæt, hi fɛlt ə tɛmteɪʃən tə tʃɹʌs hɝ, sɪns ʃi hæd wʌns tʃɹaɪd tə seɪv ɪz laɪf. ɪt wɑz oʊnli kəz ə hɝ, sæmɪtsu ən deɪmɝ flɪn ðət ɹænd hæd sɝvaɪvd. wʌn ə tu wunz ɪn ɹændz saɪd ðət wəd nɑt hil - ə ɡɪft fɹəm pdən feɪnz kɝs dæɡɝ - stɪl lɪŋɡɝɾ əz ə ɹimaɪndɝ ə ðət deɪ.

That was past. Elza had sworn. That was enough to allow Rand to use her. The other woman attending him today was less predictable; she was a member of Cadsuane's retinue. Corele Hovian -  a slim Yellow with blue eyes, wild dark hair, and a perpetual smile - had sworn no oaths to do as he said. Despite that, he felt a temptation to trust her, since she had once tried to save his life. It was only because of her, Samitsu and Damer Flinn that Rand had survived. One of two wounds in Rand's side that would not heal - a gift from Padan Fain's cursed dagger - still lingered as a reminder of that day.

ðə kɑnstən peɪn ə ðət fɛstɝɪŋ ivəl oʊvɝleɪd ði ikwəl peɪn ʌv ən oʊldɝ waʊn bɪniθ, ðə wʌn ɹænd hæd teɪkən waɪl faɪɾɪŋ ɪʃəml soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ.

The constant pain of that festering evil overlaid the equal pain of an older wound beneath, the one Rand had taken while fighting Ishamael so long ago.

sun, wʌn ə ðoʊz wunz - əɹ pɝhæps boʊθ - wəd spɪl ɹændz blʌɾ ɑntu ðə ɹɑks ə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. hi wɑzn sɝɾən ɪf ðeɪ wəd bi wʌt kɪld ɪm əɹ nɑt; wɪð ðə nʌmbɝ ən vɝaɪəɾi ʌv ðə dɪfɹən fæktɝz kəmpiɾɪŋ tə teɪk ɹændz laɪf, ivən mæt wʊdn əv noʊn wɪtʃ wʌn wɑz ðə bɛs bɛt.

Soon, one of those wounds - or perhaps both - would spill Rand's blood onto the rocks of Shayol Ghul. He wasn't certain if they would be what killed him or not; with the number and variety of the different factors competing to take Rand's life, even Mat wouldn't have known which one was the best bet.

əz sun əz ɹænd θɔɾ ə mæt, ðə kʌlɝz swɝld ɪn ɪz vɪʒən, fɔɹmɪŋ ɪndə ði ɪmədʒ ʌv ə wɪɹi, bɹaʊn-aɪd mæn wɛɹɪŋ ə waɪd-bɹɪm hæɾ ən tɔsɪŋ daɪs bɪfɔɹ ə smɔl kɹaʊɾ ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ soʊlʒɝz. mæt wɔɹ ə ɡɹɪn ən sim tə bi ʃoʊɪŋ ɔf, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑɾ ənjuʒəwəl, ðoʊ ðəɹ dɪdn sim tə bi ɛni kɔɪn tʃeɪnʒɪŋ hænz fəɹ ɪz θɹoʊz.

As soon as Rand thought of Mat, the colors swirled in his vision, forming into the image of a wiry, brown-eyed man wearing a wide-brimmed hat and tossing dice before a small crowd of watching soldiers. Mat wore a grin and seemed to be showing off, which was not unusual, though there didn't seem to be any coin changing hands for his throws.

ðə vɪʒənz keɪm wɛnɛvɝ i θɔɾ ə mæt əɹ pɛɹɪn, ən ɹænd hæd stɑp dɪsmɪsɪŋ ðɛm.

The visions came whenever he thought of Mat or Perrin, and Rand had stopped dismissing them.

hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt kɑz ði ɪmədʒəz tə əpɪɹ; pɹɑbli hɪz tɑvɝən neɪtʃɝ ɪntɝæktɪŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ tu tɑvɝən fɹəm ɪz hoʊm vɪlədʒ. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, hi juzd ɪt. dʒʌst ənʌðɝ tul. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət mæt wɑz stɪl wɪð ðə bænd, bʌt wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kæmpt ɪn ə fɔɹəstəd lænd. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə tɛl fɹəm ði æŋɡəl, bʌɾ i lʊk tə bi aʊtsaɪɾ ə sɪɾi sʌmwɛɹ. ət list, ðət wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ ɹoʊɾ ɪn ðə nɪɹ dɪstəns. ɹænd hæd nɑt sin ðə smɔl, dɑɹk-skɪnd wʊmən wɪð mæt fəɹ səm taɪm. hu wɑz ʃi?

He did not know what caused the images to appear; probably his ta'veren nature interacting with the other two ta'veren from his home village. Whatever it was, he used it. Just another tool. It appeared that Mat was still with the Band, but was no longer camped in a forested land. It was hard to tell from the angle, but he looked to be outside a city somewhere. At least, that was a large road in the near distance. Rand had not seen the small, dark-skinned woman with Mat for some time. Who was she?

wɛɹ hæd ʃi ɡɔn?

Where had she gone?

ðə vɪʒən feɪɾəd. hoʊpfəli, mæt wəd ɹɪtɝn tə hɪm sun. hi wəd nid mæt ən ɪz tæktɪkəl skɪlz ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

The vision faded. Hopefully, Mat would return to him soon. He would need Mat and his tactical skills at Shayol Ghul.

wʌn ə bæʃɪɹz kɔɹɾɝmæstɝz - ə θɪk-mʌstæʃt mæn wɪð boʊlɛɡz ən ə skwɑt bɑɾi - sɔ ɹænd ən əpɹoʊtʃt wɪð ə kwɪk stɛp. ɹænd weɪv ðə sɑldəiən bæk; hi hæd noʊ maɪn fəɹ səplaɪ ɹɪpɔɹts ət ðə moʊmənt. ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ səluɾəd ɪmiɾiətli ən ɹitʃɹiɾəd. wʌns, ɹænd maɪɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ kwɪkli hi wɑz oʊbeɪd, bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. ɪt wɑz ɹaɪt fəɹ ðə soʊlʒɝz tə oʊbeɪ.

One of Bashere's quartermasters - a thick-mustached man with bowlegs and a squat body - saw Rand and approached with a quick step. Rand waved the Saldaean back; he had no mind for supply reports at the moment. The quartermaster saluted immediately and retreated. Once, Rand might have been surprised at how quickly he was obeyed, but no longer. It was right for the soldiers to obey.

ɹænd wɑz ə kɪŋ, ðoʊ hi dɪdnt wɛɹ ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz ət ðə moʊmənt.

Rand was a king, though he didn't wear the Crown of Swords at the moment.

ɹænd pæs θɹu ðə ɡɹin, fɪld wɪð tɛns ən hɔɹs pɪkəts naʊ. hi lɛf ðə kæmp, pæsɪŋ ði ənfɪnɪʃt ɝθən bʊlwɝk. hɪɹ, paɪn tʃɹiz kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə saɪdz ə ðə dʒɛntəl sloʊp. tʌkt ɪndə ə stæn ə tʃɹiz dʒʌs tə ðə ɹaɪt wɑz ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd, ə skwɛɹ sɛkʃən ʌv ɡɹaʊn ɹoʊpt ɔf tə pɹəvaɪɾ ə seɪf loʊkeɪʃən fəɹ ɡeɪtweɪz.

Rand passed through the green, filled with tents and horse pickets now. He left the camp, passing the unfinished earthen bulwark. Here, pine trees continued down the sides of the gentle slope. Tucked into a stand of trees just to the right was the Traveling ground, a square section of ground roped off to provide a safe location for gateways.

wʌn hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ ət ðət moʊmənt, ən oʊpənɪŋ tə ənʌðɝ pleɪs. ə smɔl ɡɹup ə pipəl wɑz meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu, wɔkɪŋ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə pɪnəkoʊni-stʃɹun ɡɹaʊnd. ɹænd kəd si ðə wivz ðət meɪɾ ʌp ðə ɡeɪtweɪ; ðɪs wʌn hæd bɪn kɹæftɪd wɪð seɪɾɪn.

One hung in the air at that moment, an opening to another place. A small group of people was making their way through, walking out onto the pinecone-strewn ground. Rand could see the weaves that made up the gateway; this one had been crafted with saidin.

moʊst ə ðə pipəl ɪn ðə ɡɹup wɔɹ ðə kʌlɝfəl kloʊðɪŋ ə si foʊk - ðə mɛn bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd, ivən ɪn ðə tʃɪl spɹɪŋ ɛɹ, ðə wɪmən ɪn lus bɹaɪt blaʊsəz. ɔl wɔɹ lus tʃɹaʊzɝz, ən ɔl hæd pɪɹsɪŋz ɪn ðɛɹ ɪɹz əɹ noʊzɪz, ðə kəmplɛksəɾi ʌv ði ədɔɹnməns ən ɪndəkeɪʃən ʌv itʃ pɝsənz ɹɛləɾɪv stæɾəs.

Most of the people in the group wore the colorful clothing of Sea Folk - the men bare-chested, even in the chill spring air, the women in loose bright blouses. All wore loose trousers, and all had piercings in their ears or noses, the complexity of the adornments an indication of each person's relative status.

əz i weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə si foʊk, wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz u ɡɑɹɾəd ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊn əpɹoʊtʃt ɹænd wɪð ə sild lɛɾɝ. ðə lɛɾɝ wəd bi wʌn sɛn vaɪə æʃəmən fɹəm wʌn ə ɹændz ɪntʃɹəsts ɪn ði ist. ɪndid, əz i oʊpən ɪt, hi faʊn ɪt wɑz fɹəm dɑɹlɪn, ðə tɛɹən kɪŋ. ɹænd hæd lɛft ɪm wɪð ɔɹɾɝz tə ɡæðɝ ən ɑɹmi ən pɹipɛɹ ɪt fəɹ mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪndə ɑɹæd dumən. ðət ɡæðɝɪŋ hæd bɪn kəmpliɾəd fəɹ səm taɪm naʊ, ən dɑɹlɪn wʌndɝd - jɛɾ əɡɛn - əbaʊɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz. kəd noʊ wʌn sɪmpli də əz ðeɪ wɝ toʊld?

As he waited for the Sea Folk, one of the soldiers who guarded the Traveling ground approached Rand with a sealed letter. The letter would be one sent via Asha'man from one of Rand's interests in the east. Indeed, as he opened it, he found it was from Darlin, the Tairen king. Rand had left him with orders to gather an army and prepare it for marching into Arad Doman. That gathering had been completed for some time now, and Darlin wondered - yet again - about his orders. Could no one simply do as they were told?

"sɛn ə mɛsənʒɝ," ɹænd sɛd tə ðə soʊlʒɝ, ɪmpeɪʃənli tʌkɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ əweɪ. "tɛl dɑɹlɪn tə kəntɪnju ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ. aɪ wɑn ɪm tə dʒɹæft ɛvɹi tɛɹən u kən hoʊld ə sɔɹɾ ən iðɝ tʃɹeɪn ɪm fəɹ kɑmbæɾ əɹ sɛɾ ɪm tə wɝk ɪn ðə fɔɹdʒɪz. ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz kloʊs. vɛɹi kloʊs."

"Send a messenger," Rand said to the soldier, impatiently tucking the letter away. "Tell Darlin to continue recruiting. I want him to draft every Tairen who can hold a sword and either train him for combat or set him to work in the forges. The Last Battle is close. Very close."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ðə soʊlʒɝ sɛd, səluɾɪŋ.

"Yes, my Lord Dragon," the soldier said, saluting.

"tɛl ɪm ðəɾ əl sɛn ən æʃəmən wən aɪ wɑn ɪm tə muv," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ stɪl ɪntɛn tə juz ɪm ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, bʌɾ aɪ nid tə si wʌt ði il əv dɪskʌvɝd fɝst."

"Tell him that I will send an Asha'man when I want him to move," Rand said. "I still intend to use him in Arad Doman, but I need to see what the Aiel have discovered first."

ðə soʊlʒɝ baʊɾ ən ɹitʃɹiɾəd. ɹænd tɝn bæk tə ðə si foʊk. wʌn ə ðɛm əpɹoʊtʃt hɪm.

The soldier bowed and retreated. Rand turned back to the Sea Folk. One of them approached him.

"kɔɹəmʊɹ," ʃi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ. hɑɹɪn wɑz ə hænsəm wʊmən ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, wɪð waɪt stʃɹikɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ. hɝ æθɑn maɪɹ blaʊs wɑz ʌv ə bɹaɪt blu, kʌlɝfəl ɪnʌf tə ɪmpɹɛs ə tɪŋkɝ, ən ʃi hæɾ ən ɪmpɹɛsɪv faɪv ɡoʊld ɹɪŋz ɪn itʃ ɪɹ əz wɛl əz ə noʊz tʃeɪn stʃɹʌŋ wɪð ɡoʊl mədæljənz.

"Coramoor," she said, nodding. Harine was a handsome woman in her middle years, with white streaking her hair. Her Atha'an Miere blouse was of a bright blue, colorful enough to impress a Tinker, and she had an impressive five gold rings in each ear as well as a nose chain strung with gold medallions.

"aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk jə tə kʌm ən miɾ əs pɝsənəli," hɑɹɪn kəntɪnjud.

"I did not expect you to come and meet us personally," Harine continued.

"aɪ hæv kwɛstʃənz fəɹ jə ðət kəd nɑt weɪt."

"I have questions for you that could not wait."

hɑɹɪn lʊk teɪkən əbæk. ʃi wɑz ðə si foʊk æmbæsəɾɝ tə ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, wɪtʃ wɑz ðɛɹ neɪm fəɹ ɹænd. ðeɪ wɝ æŋɡɹi wɪð ɹænd fəɹ ðə wiks i hæd spɛnt wɪθaʊɾ ə si foʊk maɪndɝ -  hi hæd pɹɑməs tə kip wʌn wɪð ɪm əɾ ɔl taɪmz - jɛt lɑɡən hæd mɛnʃən ðɛɹ hɛzəteɪʃən tə sɛn hɑɹɪn bæk. waɪ wɑz ðæt? hæd ʃi ətʃivd ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɹæŋk, meɪkɪŋ əɹ tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ətɛn hɪm?

Harine looked taken aback. She was the Sea Folk ambassador to the Coramoor, which was their name for Rand. They were angry with Rand for the weeks he had spent without a Sea Folk minder -  he had promised to keep one with him at all times - yet Logain had mentioned their hesitation to send Harine back. Why was that? Had she achieved greater rank, making her too important to attend him?

kəd wʌn bi tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ətɛn ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ? mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðə si foʊk meɪd lɪɾəl sɛns tə hɪm.

Could one be too important to attend the Coramoor? Much about the Sea Folk made little sense to him.

"aɪ wɪl ænsɝ ɪf aɪ kæn," hɑɹɪn sɛd ɡɑɹɾɪdli. bɪhaɪn hɝ, pɔɹɾɝz muv ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ bɪlɔŋɪŋz θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. flɪn stʊɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, hoʊldɪŋ ðə pɔɹɾəl oʊpən.

"I will answer if I can," Harine said guardedly. Behind her, porters moved the rest of her belongings through the gateway. Flinn stood on the other side, holding the portal open.

"ɡʊd," ɹænd sɛd, peɪsɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ bɪfɔɹ əɹ əz i spoʊk. ət taɪmz, hi fɛl soʊ taɪɝd - soʊ wɪɹi tə hɪz boʊnz - ðəɾ i nu hi hæd tə kip muvɪŋ. nɛvɝ stɑpɪŋ. ɪf i dɪd, hɪz ɛnəmiz wəd faɪn hɪm. iðɝ ðæt, əɹ ɪz oʊn ɪɡzɔstʃən, boʊθ mɛntəl ən fɪzɪkəl, wəd dʒɹæɡ hɪm daʊn.

"Good," Rand said, pacing back and forth before her as he spoke. At times, he felt so tired - so weary to his bones - that he knew he had to keep moving. Never stopping. If he did, his enemies would find him. Either that, or his own exhaustion, both mental and physical, would drag him down.

"tɛl mi ðɪs," hi dɪmændəɾ əz i peɪst. "wɛɹ ɑɹ ðə ʃɪps wɪtʃ əv bɪn pɹɑməst? ðə dəmɑni pipəl stɑɹv waɪl ɡɹeɪn ɹɑts ɪn ði ist. lɑɡən sɛd jə hæɾ əɡɹid tə maɪ dɪmænz, bʌɾ aɪ hæv sin nʌθɪŋ ə jəɹ ʃɪps. ɪts bɪn wiks!"

"Tell me this," he demanded as he paced. "Where are the ships which have been promised? The Domani people starve while grain rots in the east. Logain said you had agreed to my demands, but I have seen nothing of your ships. It has been weeks!"

"aʊɝ ʃɪps ɑɹ swɪft," hɑɹɪn sɛd tɛstəli, "bʌt ðəɹ ɪz ə ɡɹeɪt dɪstəns tə tʃɹævəl - ən wi mʌst ɡoʊ θɹu siz kəntʃɹoʊl baɪ ðə sintʃæn. ði ɪnveɪɾɝz əv bɪn ɪkstʃɹimli dɪlɪdʒənt wɪð ðɛɹ pətʃɹoʊlz, ən əɹ ʃɪps əv hæd tə tɝn bæk ən fli ɑn sɛvɹəl əkeɪʒənz. dɪd jə ɪkspɛk ðət wi wəd bi eɪbəl bɹɪŋ jəɹ fuɾ ɪn ən ɪnstənt? pɝhæps ðə kənvinjəns ə ðiz ɡeɪtweɪz əz meɪd jə ɪmpeɪʃənt, kɔɹəmʊɹ. wi mʌs dil wɪð ðə ɹiæləɾiz ə ʃɪpɪŋ ən wɔɹ ivən ɪf jə də nɑt."

"Our ships are swift," Harine said testily, "but there is a great distance to travel - and we must go through seas controlled by the Seanchan. The invaders have been extremely diligent with their patrols, and our ships have had to turn back and flee on several occasions. Did you expect that we would be able bring your food in an instant? Perhaps the convenience of these gateways has made you impatient, Coramoor. We must deal with the realities of shipping and war even if you do not."

hɝ toʊn ɪmplaɪd ðəɾ i wəɾ əv tə dil wɪð ðoʊz ɹiæləɾiz ɪn ðɪs keɪs. "aɪ ɪkspɛkt ɹɪzʌls,"

Her tone implied that he would have to deal with those realities in this case. "I expect results,"

ɹænd sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ ɪkspɛk noʊ dɪleɪz. aɪ noʊ jə də nɑt laɪk biɪŋ fɔɹs tə kip jəɹ əɡɹimənt, bʌɾ əl sʌfɝ noʊ læɡɪŋ tə pɹuv ə pɔɪnt. pipəl daɪ kəz ə jəɹ sloʊnəs."

Rand said, shaking his head. "I expect no delays. I know you do not like being forced to keep your agreement, but I will suffer no lagging to prove a point. People die because of your slowness."

hɑɹɪn lʊkt əz ɪf ʃid bɪn slæpt. "ʃʊɹli," ʃi sɛd, "ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ dʌz nɑɾ ɪmplaɪ ðət wi wəd nɑt kip tə əɹ bɑɹɡən."

Harine looked as if she'd been slapped. "Surely," she said, "the Coramoor does not imply that we would not keep to our Bargain."

ðə si foʊk wɝ stʌbɝn ən pɹaɪdfəl, weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz mɔɹ ðən moʊst. ðeɪ wɝ laɪk ən ɪntaɪɝ ɹeɪs ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. aɪ ʃəd nɑɾ ɪnsʌlt əɹ soʊ, nɑt kəz aɪm fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd əbaʊɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. "noʊ," hi faɪnəli sɛd. "noʊ, aɪ də nɑɾ ɪmplaɪ ðæt. tɛl mi, hɑɹɪn, wɝ jə pʌnɪʃt mʌtʃ fəɹ jəɹ pɑɹɾ ɪn əɹ əɡɹimənt?"

The Sea Folk were stubborn and prideful, Wavemistresses more than most. They were like an entire race of Aes Sedai. He hesitated. I should not insult her so, not because I am frustrated about other things. "No," he finally said. "No, I do not imply that. Tell me, Harine, were you punished much for your part in our agreement?"

"aɪ wɑz hʌŋ ʌp baɪ maɪ æŋkəlz neɪkəɾ ən stʃɹæpt əntɪl aɪ kəd skɹim noʊ mɔɹ." əz sun əz ðə wɝdz lɛft əɹ maʊð, hɝ aɪz oʊpən ɪn ʃɑk. ɔfən, wən ɪnfluəns baɪ ɹændz tɑvɝən neɪtʃɝ, pipəl sɛd θɪŋz ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə ədmɪt.

"I was hung up by my ankles naked and strapped until I could scream no more." As soon as the words left her mouth, her eyes opened in shock. Often, when influenced by Rand's ta'veren nature, people said things they did not intend to admit.

"soʊ hɑɹʃ?" ɹænd sɛd, dʒɛnjəwənli sɝpɹaɪzd.

"So harsh?" Rand said, genuinely surprised.

"ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ bæɾ əz ɪt kəɾ əv bɪn. aɪ ɹɪteɪn maɪ pəzɪʃən əz weɪvməstʃɹəs fəɹ maɪ klæn."

"It was not so bad as it could have been. I retain my position as Wavemistress for my clan."

bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ʃi hæd lɔst ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə feɪs, əɹ ɪnkɝd ɡɹeɪt toʊ, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ðə blæstəd si foʊk kɔld ɑnɝ. ivən wən i wɑzn pɹɛzənt, hi kɑz peɪn ən sʌfɝɪŋ!

But it was obvious she had lost a great deal of face, or incurred great toh, or whatever the blasted Sea Folk called honor. Even when he wasn't present, he caused pain and suffering!

"aɪ æm ɡlæd juv ɹɪtɝnd," hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə seɪ. noʊ smaɪl, bʌɾ ə sɑftɝ toʊn. ðət wɑz ðə bɛst i kəd du. "ju hæv ɪmpɹɛs mi, hɑɹɪn, wɪð jəɹ lɛvlhɛɾədnəs."

"I am glad you have returned," he forced himself to say. No smile, but a softer tone. That was the best he could do. "You have impressed me, Harine, with your levelheadedness."

ʃi nɑɾəd ɪn θæŋks tə hɪm. "wi wɪl kip əɹ bɑɹɡən, kɔɹəmʊɹ. jə nidn fɪɹ."

She nodded in thanks to him. "We will keep our Bargain, Coramoor. You needn't fear."

sʌmθɪŋ ɛls stʃɹʌk hɪm, wʌn ə ði ɝɪdʒənəl kwɛstʃənz hid kʌm tə æsk hɝ. "hɑɹɪn. aɪ wəɾ æsk jə ə sʌmwʌt dɛləkət kwɛstʃən əbaʊt jəɹ pipəl."

Something else struck him, one of the original questions he'd come to ask her. "Harine. I would ask you a somewhat delicate question about your people."

"ju meɪ æsk," ʃi sɛd kɛɹfəli.

"You may ask," she said carefully.

"haʊ də ðə si foʊk tʃɹit mɛn u kən tʃænəl?"

"How do the Sea Folk treat men who can channel?"

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ðæɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə mæɾɝ fəɹ ðə ʃɔɹbaʊn tə noʊ."

She hesitated. "That is not a matter for the shorebound to know."

ɹænd mɛɾ əɹ aɪz. "ɪf jə əɡɹi tə ænsɝ, ðən əl ænsɝ ə kwɛstʃən fəɹ jə ɪn ɹɪtɝn." ðə bɛst weɪ tə dil wɪð ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɑz nɑt tə pʊʃ əɹ bʊli, bʌt tə ɔfɝ tʃɹeɪd.

Rand met her eyes. "If you agree to answer, then I will answer a question for you in return." The best way to deal with the Atha'an Miere was not to push or bully, but to offer trade.

ʃi pɔzd. "ɪf jə ɡɪmi tu kwɛstʃənz," ʃi sɛd, "aɪ wɪl ænsɝ."

She paused. "If you give me two questions," she said, "I will answer."

"aɪ wɪl ɡɪv jə wʌn kwɛstʃən, hɑɹɪn," hi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ. "bʌɾ aɪ pɹɑməs tə ænsɝ jə əz tʃɹuθfəli əz aɪ kæn. ɪts ə fɛɹ bɑɹɡən, ən jə noʊ ɪt. aɪ hæv lɪɾəl peɪʃəns ɹaɪt naʊ."

"I will give you one question, Harine," he said, raising a finger. "But I promise to answer you as truthfully as I can. It is a fair bargain, and you know it. I have little patience right now."

hɑɹɪn tʌtʃt əɹ fɪŋɡɝz tə hɝ lɪps. "ɪɾ ɪz əɡɹid, ðɛn, ʌndɝ ðə laɪt."

Harine touched her fingers to her lips. "It is agreed, then, under the Light."

"ɪɾ ɪz əɡɹid," ɹænd sɛd. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt. maɪ kwɛstʃən?"

"It is agreed," Rand said. "Under the Light. My question?"

"mɛn u kən tʃænəl ɑɹ ɡɪvən ə tʃɔɪs," hɑɹɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ kən iðɝ stɛp fɹəm ðə baʊ ʌv ðɛɹ ʃɪp hoʊldɪŋ ə stoʊn wɪtʃ ɪz ɔlsoʊ taɪd tə ðɛɹ lɛɡz, əɹ ðeɪ kən bi dʒɹɑpt ɔf ɑn ə bæɹən aɪl wɪð noʊ fuɾ əɹ wɔɾɝ. ðə sɛkən ɪz kənsɪɾɝd ðə mɔɹ ʃeɪmfəl ɑpʃən, bʌt səm fju də teɪk ɪt, tə lɪv fəɹ ə bɹif taɪm lɔŋɡɝ."

"Men who can channel are given a choice," Harine said. "They can either step from the bow of their ship holding a stone which is also tied to their legs, or they can be dropped off on a barren isle with no food or water. The second is considered the more shameful option, but some few do take it, to live for a brief time longer."

nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌɾ ɪz oʊn pipəl dɪɾ ɪn dʒɛntəlɪŋ mɛn, tʃɹuθ bi toʊld. "seɪɾɪn ɪz klɛnz naʊ," hi sɛd tə hɝ. "ðɪs pɹæktəs mʌst stɑp."

Not much different from what his own people did in gentling men, truth be told. "Saidin is cleansed now," he said to her. "This practice must stop."

ʃi pɝst əɹ lɪps, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ hɪm. "jɔɹ . . . mæn spoʊk ə ðɪs, kɔɹəmʊɹ. səm faɪn ɪt dɪfəkəl tə æksɛpt."

She pursed her lips, regarding him. "Your . . . man spoke of this, Coramoor. Some find it difficult to accept."

"ɪɾ ɪz tʃɹu," hi sɛd fɝmli.

"It is true," he said firmly.

"aɪ də nɑt daʊt ðət jə bɪliv ɪt tə bi soʊ."

"I do not doubt that you believe it to be so."

ɹænd ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, fɔɹsɪŋ daʊn ənʌðɝ bɝst ʌv æŋɡɝ, hɪz hæn fɔɹmɪŋ ə fɪst. hi hæd klɛnz ðə teɪnt! hi, ɹænd ælθɹ, hæd pɝfɔɹmd ə did ðə laɪks ʌv wɪtʃ hæd nɑt bɪn sin sɪns ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ən haʊ wɑz ɪt tʃɹiɾəd? wɪð səspɪʃən ən daʊt. moʊst əsum ðəɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ mæd, ən ðɛɹfɔɹ siɪŋ ə "klɛnzɪŋ" ðət hæd nɑt ɹɪli hæpənd.

Rand gritted his teeth, forcing down another burst of anger, his hand forming a fist. He had cleansed the taint! He, Rand al'Thor, had performed a deed the likes of which had not been seen since the Age of Legends. And how was it treated? With suspicion and doubt. Most assumed that he was going mad, and therefore seeing a "cleansing" that had not really happened.

mɛn u kəd tʃænəl wɝ ɔlweɪz dɪstʃɹʌstəd. jɛt ðeɪ wɝ ði oʊnli wʌnz u kəd kənfɝm wʌt ɹænd sɛd! hiɾ ɪmædʒən dʒɔɪ ən wʌndɝ ət ðə vɪktɝi, bʌɾ i ʃʊɾə noʊn bɛɾɝ.

Men who could channel were always distrusted. Yet they were the only ones who could confirm what Rand said! He'd imagined joy and wonder at the victory, but he should have known better.

ðoʊ meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd wʌns bɪn əz ɹɪspɛktɪɾ əz ðɛɹ fimeɪl kaʊntɝpɑɹts, ðət hæd bɪn lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ðə deɪz ə dʒɔɹlən kɔɹbəsən hæd bɪn lɔst ɪn taɪm. ɔl pipəl kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ naʊ wɑz ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ən ðə mædnəs.

Though male Aes Sedai had once been as respected as their female counterparts, that had been long ago. The days of Jorlen Corbesan had been lost in time. All people could remember now was the Breaking and the Madness.

ðeɪ heɪɾəd meɪl tʃænlɝz. jɛt, ɪn fɑloʊɪŋ ɹænd, ðeɪ sɝvd wʌn. dɪd ðeɪ nɑt si ðə kɑntʃɹədɪkʃən? haʊ kəɾ i kənvɪns əm ðət ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹizən tə mɝɾɝ mɛn u kəd tʌtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ? hi niɾəd ðɛm! waɪ, ðəɹ maɪt bi ənʌðɝ dʒɔɹlən kɔɹbəsən əmʌŋ ðə vɛɹi mɛn ðə si foʊk tɔst ɪndə ði oʊʃən!

They hated male channelers. Yet, in following Rand, they served one. Did they not see the contradiction? How could he convince them that there was no longer reason to murder men who could touch the One Power? He needed them! Why, there might be another Jorlen Corbesan among the very men the Sea Folk tossed into the ocean!

hi fɹoʊz. dʒɔɹlən kɔɹbəsən hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə moʊs tæləntəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, ə mæn u hæd kɹæftɪd səm ə ðə moʊst əmeɪzɪŋ tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. ɪksɛpt ɹænd hæd nɑt sin ðɛm. ðoʊz wɝ luz θɝɪnz mɛmɹiz, nɑt hɪz. dʒɔɹlənz ɹisɝtʃ fəsɪlɪɾi ʌv ʃæɹəm hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd - ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf kɪld - baɪ ðə bæklæʃ ə paʊɝ fɹəm ðə bɔɹ.

He froze. Jorlen Corbesan had been one of the most talented Aes Sedai before the Breaking, a man who had crafted some of the most amazing ter'angreal Rand had ever seen. Except Rand had not seen them. Those were Lews Therin's memories, not his. Jorlen's research facility of Sharom had been destroyed - the man himself killed - by the backlash of Power from the Bore.

oʊ, laɪt, ɹænd θɔt wɪð dɪspɛɹ. aɪm luzɪŋ maɪsɛlf. luzɪŋ maɪsɛlf ɪn hɪm.

Oh, Light, Rand thought with despair. I'm losing myself. Losing myself in him.

ðə moʊs tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ pɑɹt wɑz ðət ɹænd kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ meɪk hɪmsɛlf wɪʃ tə bænɪʃ luz θɝɪn.

The most terrifying part was that Rand could no longer make himself wish to banish Lews Therin.

luz θɝɪn hæd noʊn ə weɪ tə sil ðə bɔɹ, ɪf ɪmpɝfɪkli, bʌt ɹænd hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðə tæsk. ðə seɪfti ʌv ðə wɝl maɪt dɪpɛn ɑn ðə mɛmɹiz ʌv ə dɛd mædmæn.

Lews Therin had known a way to seal the Bore, if imperfectly, but Rand had no idea how to approach the task. The safety of the world might depend on the memories of a dead madman.

mɛni ʌv ðə pipəl ɝaʊn ɹænd əpɪɹd ʃɑkt, ən hɑɹɪnz aɪz wɝ boʊθ ənkʌmftəɹbəl ən ə lɪɾəl fɹaɪɾənd. ɹænd hæd bɪn mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf əɡɛn, hi ɹilaɪzd, ən i kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli.

Many of the people around Rand appeared shocked, and Harine's eyes were both uncomfortable and a little frightened. Rand had been muttering to himself again, he realized, and he cut off abruptly.

"aɪ æksɛp jəɹ ænsɝ," hi sɛd stɪfli. "wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ kwɛstʃən ə mi?"

"I accept your answer," he said stiffly. "What is your question of me?"

"aɪ wɪl æsk ɪt leɪɾɝ," ʃi sɛd. "wʌns aɪ hæv hæɾ ə tʃæns tə kənsɪɾɝ."

"I will ask it later," she said. "Once I have had a chance to consider."

"æz jə wɪʃ." hi tɝn əweɪ, hɪz ɹɛɾənu ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, meɪɾənz ən ətɛndəns fɑloʊɪŋ.

"As you wish." He turned away, his retinue of Aes Sedai, Maidens and attendants following.

"ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd ɡɑɹdz wɪl si jə tə jəɹ ɹum ən kæɹi jəɹ lʌɡədʒ." ðəɹ wɑz ə vɛɹɪɾəbəl maʊntən ə ðæt. "flɪn, tə mi!"

"The Traveling ground guards will see you to your room and carry your luggage." There was a veritable mountain of that. "Flinn, to me!"

ði ɛldɝli æʃəmən dʒʌmp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, moʊʃənɪŋ fəɹ ðə læst ə ðə pɔɹɾɝz tə tʃɹɑt bæk tə ðə dɑks ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. hi lɛt ðə pɔɹɾəl twɪs bæk ɪndə ə slæʃ ə laɪɾ ən vænɪʃ, ðən hɝiɾ æftɝ ɹænd. hi spɛɹɾ ə ɡlæns ən ə smaɪl fəɹ kɔɹəl, hu hæd bɑndəɾ ɪm əz əɹ wɔɹɾɝ.

The elderly Asha'man jumped through the gateway, motioning for the last of the porters to trot back to the docks on the other side. He let the portal twist back into a slash of light and vanish, then hurried after Rand. He spared a glance and a smile for Corele, who had bonded him as her Warder.

"aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ teɪkɪŋ soʊ lɔŋ tə ɹɪtɝn, lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." flɪn hæɾ ə lɛðɝi feɪs ən oʊnli ə fju wɪsps ə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd. hi lʊkt ə lɑt laɪk səm ə ðə fɑɹmɝz ɹænd hæd noʊn bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, ðoʊ hi hæd bɪn ə soʊlʒɝ fəɹ moʊst ə hɪz laɪf. flɪn hæd kʌm tə ɹænd kəz i wɑntəd tə lɝn hilɪŋ. ɹænd hæd tɝn ɪm ɪndə ə wɛpən ɪnstɛd.

"I apologize for taking so long to return, Lord Dragon." Flinn had a leathery face and only a few wisps of hair on his head. He looked a lot like some of the farmers Rand had known back in Emond's Field, though he had been a soldier for most of his life. Flinn had come to Rand because he wanted to learn Healing. Rand had turned him into a weapon instead.

"ju dɪɾ əz ɔɹɾɝd," ɹænd sɛd, wɔkɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹin. hi wɑntəd tə bleɪm hɑɹɪn fəɹ ðə pɹɛdʒəɾɪsɪz ʌv ən ɪntaɪɝ wɝld, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt fɛɹ. hi niɾəd ə bɛɾɝ weɪ, ə weɪ tə meɪk ɛvɹiwʌn si.

"You did as ordered," Rand said, walking back toward the green. He wanted to blame Harine for the prejudices of an entire world, but that was not fair. He needed a better way, a way to make everyone see.

"aɪv nɛvɝ bɪn ɪksɛpʃənəl ət meɪkɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz," flɪn kəntɪnjud. "nɑt laɪk ænʒɹəl. aɪ niɾəd tə  - "

"I've never been exceptional at making gateways," Flinn continued. "Not like Androl. I needed to  - "

"flɪn," ɹænd sɛd, kʌɾɪŋ ɪn. "ɪnʌf."

"Flinn," Rand said, cutting in. "Enough."

ði æʃəmən blʌʃt. "aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən."

The Asha'man blushed. "I apologize, my Lord Dragon."

tə ðə saɪd, kɔɹəl læf sɔfli, pæɾɪŋ flɪn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. "doʊn maɪn hɪm, deɪmɝ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə lɪltɪŋ mʊɹændiən æksɛnt. "hiz bɪn əz sɝli əz ə wɪntɝ θʌndɝhɛɾ ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ."

To the side, Corele laughed softly, patting Flinn on the shoulder. "Don't mind him, Damer," she said in a lilting Murandian accent. "He's been as surly as a winter thunderhead all morning."

ɹænd ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɝ, bʌt ʃi dʒʌst smaɪld ɡʊd-neɪtʃɝdli. ɹəɡɑɹdləs ʌv wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ θɔɾ ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl ɪn dʒɛnɝəl, ðə wʌnz u hæd teɪkən æʃəmən əz wɔɹɾɝz simd əz pɹətɛktɪv ə ðɛm əz mʌðɝz ə ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən. ʃi hæd bɑndəd wʌn ə hɪz mɛn, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ðə fæk ðət flɪn wɑz wʌn ə hɪz mɛn. ən æʃəmən fɝst ən fɔɹmoʊst, ə wɔɹɾɝ sɛkənd.

Rand glared at her, but she just smiled good-naturedly. Regardless of what the Aes Sedai thought of men who could channel in general, the ones who had taken Asha'man as Warders seemed as protective of them as mothers of their children. She had bonded one of his men, but that did not change the fact that Flinn was one of his men. An Asha'man first and foremost, a Warder second.

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk, ɛlzə?" ɹænd sɛd, tɝnɪŋ fɹəm kɔɹəl tə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. "əbaʊt ðə teɪn ən wʌt hɑɹɪn sɛd?"

"What do you think, Elza?" Rand said, turning from Corele to the other Aes Sedai. "About the taint and what Harine said?"

ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ʃi wɔkt wɪð hænz bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk, dɑɹk ɡɹin dʒɹɛs mɑɹkt oʊnli baɪ sʌɾəl ɪmbɹɔɪɾɝiz. jutɪlətɛɹiən, fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. "ɪf maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən sɛz ðət ðə teɪn əz bɪn klɛnzd," ðə wʊmən sɛd kɛɹfəli, "ðɛn ɪts sɝɾənli ɪmpɹɑpɝ tə ɪkspɹɛs daʊɾ ə hɪm wɛɹ ʌðɝz kən hɪɹ."

The round-faced woman hesitated. She walked with hands behind her back, dark green dress marked only by subtle embroideries. Utilitarian, for an Aes Sedai. "If my Lord Dragon says that the taint has been cleansed," the woman said carefully, "then it is certainly improper to express doubt of him where others can hear."

ɹænd ɡɹɪməst. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ænsɝ fəɹ sɝɾən. oʊθ əɹ noʊ oʊθ, ɛlzə dɪɾ əz ʃi wɪʃt.

Rand grimaced. An Aes Sedai answer for certain. Oath or no oath, Elza did as she wished.

"oʊ, wi wɝ boʊθ ðəɹ ət ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ," kɔɹəl sɛd, ɹoʊlɪŋ əɹ aɪz. "wi sɔ wʌt jə dɪd, ɹænd. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ kən fil meɪl paʊɝ θɹu dɪɹ deɪmɝ hɪɹ wən wi lɪŋk. ɪts tʃeɪnʒd. ðə teɪn ɪz ɡɔn. ɹaɪɾ əz sʌnlaɪt, ɪɾ ɪz, ðoʊ tʃænəlɪŋ ðə meɪl hæf stɪl filz laɪk ɹɛslɪŋ wɪð ə sʌmɝ wɝlwɪnd."

"Oh, we were both there at Shadar Logoth," Corele said, rolling her eyes. "We saw what you did, Rand. Besides, I can feel male power through dear Damer here when we link. It has changed. The taint is gone. Right as sunlight, it is, though channeling the male half still feels like wrestling with a summer whirlwind."

"jɛs," ɛlzə sɛd, "bʌt bi ðəɾ əz ɪɾ ɪz, jə mʌst ɹilaɪz haʊ dɪfəkəlt ɪɾəl bi fəɹ ʌðɝz tə bɪliv ðɪs, lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. dʊɹɪŋ ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, ɪt tʊk dɛkeɪdz fəɹ səm pipəl tə æksɛp ðət ðə meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ dum tə ɡoʊ ɪnseɪn. ɪɾəl laɪkli teɪk lɔŋɡɝ fəɹ əm tə oʊvɝkʌm ðɛɹ dɪstʃɹʌst, naʊ ðəɾ ɪts bɪn ɪnɡɹeɪn fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ."

"Yes," Elza said, "but be that as it is, you must realize how difficult it will be for others to believe this, Lord Dragon. During the Time of Madness, it took decades for some people to accept that the male Aes Sedai were doomed to go insane. It will likely take longer for them to overcome their distrust, now that it has been ingrained for so long."

ɹænd ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. hi hæd ɹitʃt ə smɔl hɪl ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp, dʒʌs bɪsaɪd ðə bʊlwɝk.

Rand gritted his teeth. He had reached a small hill at the side of the camp, just beside the bulwark.

hi kəntɪnjuɾ ʌp tə ðə tɑp, ɛɛs sədaɪ fɑloʊɪŋ. hɪɹ, ə ʃɔɹt wʊɾən plætfɔɹm hæd bɪn ɪɹɛktəd - ə faɪɝ taʊɝ fəɹ lɔntʃɪŋ æɹoʊz oʊvɝ ðə bʊlwɝk.

He continued up to the top, Aes Sedai following. Here, a short wooden platform had been erected - a fire tower for launching arrows over the bulwark.

ɹænd stɑpt ət ðə tɑp ə ðə hɪl, meɪɾənz sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪm. hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðə soʊlʒɝz u səluɾəd ɪm əz i lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə sɑldəiən kæmp wɪð ɪts nit tɛn laɪnz.

Rand stopped at the top of the hill, Maidens surrounding him. He barely noticed the soldiers who saluted him as he looked over the Saldaean camp with its neat tent lines.

wɑz ðɪs ɔl i wəd liv tə ðə wɝld? ə teɪn klɛnzd, jɛt mɛn stɪl kɪld əɹ ɛɡzaɪl fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd nɑt hɛlp? hi hæd baʊn moʊs neɪʃənz tə hɪm. jɛɾ i nu wɛl ðət ðə taɪɾɝ wʌn taɪɾ ə beɪl, ðə ʃɑɹpɝ ðə snæp ə ðə kɔɹdz wən ðeɪ wɝ kʌt. wʌt wəd hæpən wən i daɪd? wɔɹz ən dɛvəsteɪʃən tə mætʃ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ? hi hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə hɛlp ðət læs taɪm, fəɹ ɪz mædnəs ən ɡɹif əɾ aɪlaɪɛnəz dɛθ hæd kənsum hɪm. kəɾ i pɹɪvɛn sʌmθɪŋ sɪməlɝ ðɪs taɪm?

Was this all he would leave to the world? A taint cleansed, yet men still killed or exiled for something they could not help? He had bound most nations to him. Yet he knew well that the tighter one tied a bale, the sharper the snap of the cords when they were cut. What would happen when he died? Wars and devastation to match the Breaking? He hadn't been able to help that last time, for his madness and grief at Ilyena's death had consumed him. Could he prevent something similar this time?

dɪɾ i hæv ə tʃɔɪs?

Did he have a choice?

hi wɑz tɑvɝən. ðə pæɾɝn bɛn ən ʃeɪpt ɝaʊn hɪm. ən jɛt, hi hæd kwɪkli lɝnd wʌn θɪŋ fɹəm biɪŋ ə kɪŋ: ðə mɔɹ əθɔɹəɾi jə ɡeɪnd, ðə lɛs kəntʃɹoʊl jə hæɾ oʊvɝ jəɹ laɪf. duɾi wɑz tʃɹuli hɛviɝ ðən ə maʊntən; ɪt fɔɹst ɪz hæn əz ɔfən əz ðə pɹɑfəsiz dɪd. əɹ wɝ ðeɪ boʊθ wʌn ən ðə seɪm? duɾi ən pɹɑfəsi? hɪz neɪtʃɝ əz ə tɑvɝən ən ɪz pleɪs ɪn hɪstɝi? kəɾ i tʃeɪnʒ ɪz laɪf? kəɾ i liv ðə wɝl bɛɾɝ fəɹ ɪz pæsɪŋ, ɹæðɝ ðən livɪŋ ðə neɪʃənz skɑɹd, tɔɹn ən bliɾɪŋ?

He was ta'veren. The Pattern bent and shaped around him. And yet, he had quickly learned one thing from being a king: the more authority you gained, the less control you had over your life. Duty was truly heavier than a mountain; it forced his hand as often as the prophecies did. Or were they both one and the same? Duty and prophecy? His nature as a ta'veren and his place in history? Could he change his life? Could he leave the world better for his passing, rather than leaving the nations scarred, torn and bleeding?

hi wɑtʃt ðə kæmp, mɛn muvɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ tæsks, hɔɹsəz noʊzɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ pætʃəz ʌv wɪntɝ ɡɹæs ðət hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn tʃud tə ðɛɹ ɹuts. ðoʊ ɹænd hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðɪs ɑɹmi tə tʃɹævəl laɪt, ðəɹ wɝ stɪl kæmp fɑloʊɝz. wɪmən tə hɛlp wɪð milz ən lɔnʒɹi, blæksmɪθs ən fɛɹiɝz tə tɛn hɔɹsəz ən ɪkwɪpmənt, jʌŋ bɔɪz tə ɹʌn mɛsədʒəz ən tə tʃɹeɪn ɑn ðə wɛpənz. sɑldɑiə wɑz ə bɔɹɾɝlənd, ən bæɾəl wɑz ə weɪ ʌv laɪf fəɹ ɪts pipəl.

He watched the camp, men moving about their tasks, horses nosing at the ground, searching for patches of winter grass that had not already been chewed to their roots. Though Rand had ordered this army to travel light, there were still camp followers. Women to help with meals and laundry, blacksmiths and farriers to tend horses and equipment, young boys to run messages and to train on the weapons. Saldaea was a Borderland, and battle was a way of life for its people.

"aɪ ɛnvi ðɛm, səmtaɪmz," ɹænd wɪspɝd.

"I envy them, sometimes," Rand whispered.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" flɪn æskt, stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə hɪm.

"My Lord?" Flinn asked, stepping up to him.

"ðə pipəl ə ðə kæmp," ɹænd sɛd. "ðeɪ də əz ðeɪ ɑɹ toʊld, wɝkɪŋ itʃ deɪ ʌndɝ ɔɹɾɝz.

"The people of the camp," Rand said. "They do as they are told, working each day under orders.

stʃɹɪkt ɔɹɾɝz, ət taɪmz. bʌɾ ɔɹɾɝz əɹ nɑt, ðoʊz pipəl ɑɹ mɔɹ fɹi ðən aɪ."

Strict orders, at times. But orders or not, those people are more free than I."

"ju, lɔɹd?" flɪn sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz lɛðɝi feɪs wɪð ən eɪdʒɪd fɪŋɡɝ. "ju ɑɹ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl mæn əlaɪv! jəɹ tɑvɝən. ivən ðə pæɾɝn oʊbeɪz jəɹ wɪl, aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk!"

"You, Lord?" Flinn said, rubbing his leathery face with an aged finger. "You are the most powerful man alive! You're ta'veren. Even the Pattern obeys your will, I should think!"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪt dʌznt wɝk ðət weɪ, flɪn. ðoʊz pipəl aʊt ðɛɹ, ɛni wʌn ə ðɛm kəd dʒʌst ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. ɪskeɪp, ɪf ðeɪ fɛlt laɪk ɪt. liv ðə bæɾəl tə ʌðɝz."

Rand shook his head. "It doesn't work that way, Flinn. Those people out there, any one of them could just ride away. Escape, if they felt like it. Leave the battle to others."

"aɪv noʊn ə fju sɑldəiənz ɪn maɪ deɪ, maɪ lɔɹd," flɪn sɛd. "fɝɡɪv mi, bʌɾ aɪ hæv daʊts ðəɾ ɛni wʌn ə ðɛm wəd də ðæt."

"I've known a few Saldaeans in my day, my Lord," Flinn said. "Forgive me, but I have doubts that any one of them would do that."

"bʌt ðeɪ kʊd," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪts pɑsəbəl. fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ lɔz ən oʊðz, ðeɪ ɑɹ fɹi. mi, aɪ sim əz ɪf aɪ kən də əz aɪ wɪʃ, bʌɾ aɪm taɪd soʊ taɪtli ðə bɑnz kʌt maɪ flɛʃ. maɪ paʊɝ ən ɪnfluəns ɑɹ minɪŋləs əɡɛns feɪt. maɪ fɹiɾəm ɪz ɔl dʒʌst ən ɪluʒən, flɪn. ən soʊ aɪ ɛnvi ðɛm. səmtaɪmz."

"But they could," Rand said. "It's possible. For all their laws and oaths, they are free. Me, I seem as if I can do as I wish, but I am tied so tightly the bonds cut my flesh. My power and influence are meaningless against fate. My freedom is all just an illusion, Flinn. And so I envy them. Sometimes."

flɪn foʊldəɾ ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, ɑbviəsli ənsɝɾən haʊ tə ɹɪspɑnd.

Flinn folded his hands behind his back, obviously uncertain how to respond.

wi ɔl də əz wi mʌst, mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs fɹəm ðə pæst ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz mɛmɹi. əz ðə pæɾɝn dɪkɹiz. fəɹ səm ðəɹ ɪz lɛs fɹiɾəm ðən fəɹ ʌðɝz. ɪt dʌz nɑt mæɾɝ wɛðɝ wi tʃuz əɹ ɑɹ tʃoʊzən. wʌt mʌs bi, mʌs bi.

We all do as we must, Moiraine's voice from the past returned to his memory. As the Pattern decrees. For some there is less freedom than for others. It does not matter whether we choose or are chosen. What must be, must be.

ʃi hæɾ ʌndɝstʊd. ɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ, mɔɪɹeɪn, hi θɔt. əl də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn.

She had understood. I'm trying, Moiraine, he thought. I will do what must be done.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən!" ə vɔɪs kɔld. ɹænd tɝn təwɔɹd ðə saʊn ən sɔ wʌn ə bæʃɪɹz skaʊts ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp ðə hɪl. ðə meɪɾənz kɔʃəsli əlaʊd ðə juθfəl, dɑɹk-hɛɹd mæn tə əpɹoʊtʃ.

"My Lord Dragon!" a voice called. Rand turned toward the sound and saw one of Bashere's scouts running up the hill. The Maidens cautiously allowed the youthful, dark-haired man to approach.

"maɪ lɔɹd," ðə skaʊt sɛd, səluɾɪŋ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ il ɑn ði aʊtskɝts ə ðə kæmp. wi sɔ tu ʌv əm pɹaʊlɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz əbaʊt hæf ə maɪl daʊn ðə sloʊp."

"My Lord," the scout said, saluting. "There are Aiel on the outskirts of the camp. We saw two of them prowling through the trees about half a mile down the slope."

ðə meɪɾənz ɪmiɾiətli bɪɡæn tə muv ðɛɹ hænz, spikɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ klændɛstɪn hæntɔk.
