The Maidens immediately began to move their hands, speaking in their clandestine handtalk.

"dɪɾ ɛni ʌv ðoʊz il weɪv ət ju, soʊlʒɝ?" ɹænd æsk dʒɹaɪli.

"Did any of those Aiel wave at you, soldier?" Rand asked dryly.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" ðə mæn æskt. "waɪ wəd ðeɪ də ðæt?"

"My Lord?" the man asked. "Why would they do that?"

"ðeɪɹ il. ɪf jə sɔ ðɛm, ðət minz ðeɪ wɑntəd jə tə - ən ðət minz ðəɹ ælaɪz, nɑt foʊz. ɪnfɔɹm bæʃɪɹ ðət wɪl bi miɾɪŋ wɪð ɹəɑɹk ən beɪl ʃɔɹtli. ɪts taɪm tə sɪkjʊɹ ɑɹæd dumən."

"They're Aiel. If you saw them, that means they wanted you to - and that means they're allies, not foes. Inform Bashere that we'll be meeting with Rhuarc and Bael shortly. It is time to secure Arad Doman."

əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz taɪm tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɪt. səmtaɪmz, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl ðə dɪfɝəns.

Or maybe it was time to destroy it. Sometimes, it was difficult to tell the difference.

mɛɹaɪs spoʊk. "ɡɹeɪndəlz plænz. tɛl mi əɡɛn wʌt jə noʊ ʌv ðɛm." ðə tɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ - ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, laɪk kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf - meɪnteɪn ə stɝn ɪkspɹɛʃən, ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, ə sɪlvɝ koʊm slɪɾ ɪndə ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ blæk hɛɹ.

Merise spoke. "Graendal's plans. Tell me again what you know of them." The tall Aes Sedai - of the Green Ajah, like Cadsuane herself - maintained a stern expression, arms folded beneath her breasts, a silver comb slid into the side of her black hair.

ðə tæɹɑbənɝ wʊmən wɑz ə ɡʊd tʃɔɪs tə lid ði ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃən. ɔɹ, ət list, ʃi wɑz ðə bɛs tʃɔɪs kædzueɪn hæd. mɛɹaɪs dɪdnt ʃoʊ ə bɪɾ ə dɪskʌmfɝɾ ət biɪŋ soʊ nɪɹ tə wʌn ə ðə moʊs fɪɹd biɪŋz ɪn ɔl ə kɹieɪʃən, ən ʃi wɑz ɹɪlɛnlɪs ɪn əɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ. ʃi dɪd tʃɹaɪ ə lɪɾəl tu hɑɹd tə pɹuv haʊ stɝn ʃi wɑz. ðə weɪ ʃi kɛpt əɹ hɛɹ pʊl bæk ɪndə ɪts bʌn wɪð sətʃ fɔɹs, fəɹ ɪnstəns, əɹ ðə weɪ ʃi flɔntɪɾ əɹ æʃəmən wɔɹɾɝ.

The Taraboner woman was a good choice to lead the interrogation. Or, at least, she was the best choice Cadsuane had. Merise didn't show a bit of discomfort at being so near to one of the most feared beings in all of creation, and she was relentless in her questioning. She did try a little too hard to prove how stern she was. The way she kept her hair pulled back into its bun with such force, for instance, or the way she flaunted her Asha'man Warder.

ðə ɹum wɑz ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ ə ɹænd ælθɹz dəmɑni mænʃən, ði aʊɾɝ wɔl meɪɾ ə θɪk ɹaʊn paɪn lɔɡz, ði ɪnɝ wɔlz ʌv wʊd plæŋks, ɔl steɪn ə mætʃɪŋ dɑɹk kʌlɝ. ðɪs tʃeɪmbɝ, wɪtʃ hæd wʌns bɪn ə bɛdʒɹum, hæd bɪn ɛmptiɾ ə nɪɹli ɔl fɝnɪtʃɝ; ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ivən ə ɹʌɡ ɑn ðə sændɪd wʊd flɔɹ. ɪn fækt, ði oʊnli fɝnɪtʃɝ ɪn ɪt naʊ wɑz ðə staʊt tʃɛɹ kædzueɪn sæɾ ɪn.

The room was on the second floor of Rand al'Thor's Domani mansion, the outer wall made of thick round pine logs, the inner walls of wood planks, all stained a matching dark color. This chamber, which had once been a bedroom, had been emptied of nearly all furniture; there was not even a rug on the sanded wood floor. In fact, the only furniture in it now was the stout chair Cadsuane sat in.

kædzueɪn sɪpt əɹ ti, ɪntɛnʃənəli pɹədʒɛktɪŋ ən ɛɹ ə kəmpoʊʒɝ. ðət wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ɪspɛʃli ɪf wʌn wɑzn ɛniθɪŋ nɪɹ kəmpoʊzd ɑn ði ɪnsaɪd. ət ðə moʊmənt, fəɹ ɪnstəns, kædzueɪn wɑntəd tə kɹʌʃ ðə tikʌp bɪtwin əɹ hænz, ðən pɝhæps spɛn ən aʊɝ əɹ soʊ stæmpɪŋ ɑn ðə ʃɑɹdz.

Cadsuane sipped her tea, intentionally projecting an air of composure. That was important, especially if one wasn't anything near composed on the inside. At the moment, for instance, Cadsuane wanted to crush the teacup between her hands, then perhaps spend an hour or so stamping on the shards.

ʃi tʊk ənʌðɝ sɪp.

She took another sip.

ðə sɔɹs ə hɝ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən - ən ði əbdʒɛkt ə mɛɹaɪsəz kwɛstʃənɪŋ - hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, hɛld ʌpsaɪd daʊn baɪ wivz ʌv ɛɹ wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz taɪd bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk. ðə kæptɪv hæd ʃɔɹt weɪvi hɛɹ ən dɑɹk skɪn. hɝ feɪs mætʃt kædzueɪnz oʊn fəɹ kəmpoʊz sɝɛnəɾi, dɪspaɪɾ əɹ sɝkəmstænsəz.

The source of her frustration - and the object of Merise's questioning - hung in the air, held upside down by weaves of Air with her arms tied behind her back. The captive had short wavy hair and dark skin. Her face matched Cadsuane's own for composed serenity, despite her circumstances.

wɛɹɪŋ ə sɪmpəl bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs - ðə hɛm hɛld ʌp ɝaʊn əɹ lɛɡz baɪ ə wiv ʌv ɛɹ tə kip ɪt fɹəm əbskjʊɹɪŋ əɹ feɪs - hɛl baʊn ən ʃildɪd, ðə pɹɪznɝ sʌmhaʊ sim ðə wʌn ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl.

Wearing a simple brown dress - the hem held up around her legs by a weave of Air to keep it from obscuring her face - held bound and shielded, the prisoner somehow seemed the one in control.

mɛɹaɪs stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə pɹɪznɝ. nɛɹɪʃmə lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ði oʊnli ʌðɝ wʌn ɪn ðə ɹum.

Merise stood in front of the prisoner. Narishma leaned against the wall, the only other one in the room.

kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt kəntʃɹoʊl ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ hɝsɛlf, nɑt jɛt. lɛɾɪŋ ənʌðɝ lɛd ði ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃən wɝk tə hɝ ædvæntɪdʒ; ɪt lɛɾ əɹ θɪŋk ən plæn. aʊtsaɪd ðə ɹum, ɛɹiən, sɝin, ən nɛsun hɛl ðə pɹɪznɝz ʃild, tu mɔɹ ðən wɝ nɔɹməli kənsɪɾɝd nɛsəsɛɹi.

Cadsuane did not control the questioning herself, not yet. Letting another lead the interrogation worked to her advantage; it let her think and plan. Outside the room, Erian, Sarene, and Nesune held the prisoner's shield, two more than were normally considered necessary.

wʌn dɪd nɑt teɪk tʃænsəz wɪð ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

One did not take chances with the Forsaken.

ðɛɹ pɹɪznɝ wɑz sɛmɝhɪdʒ. ə mɑnstɝ u mɛni θɔt wɑz sɪmpli ə lɛdʒənd. kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ mɛni ʌv ðə stɔɹiz əbaʊt ðə wʊmən wɝ tʃɹu. ʃi dɪd noʊ ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz nɑɾ izəli ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd, ənsɛɾəld əɹ mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd. ən ðət wɑz ə pɹɑbləm.

Their prisoner was Semirhage. A monster who many thought was simply a legend. Cadsuane did not know how many of the stories about the woman were true. She did know that Semirhage was not easily intimidated, unsettled or manipulated. And that was a problem.

"wɛl?" mɛɹaɪs dɪmændəd. "maɪ kwɛstʃən: juv ən ænsɝ?"

"Well?" Merise demanded. "My question: you have an answer?"

sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd mɛɹaɪs, aɪsi kəntɛmpt ɪn əɹ vɔɪs əz ʃi spoʊk. "du jə noʊ wʌt hæpənz tə ə mæn wən ɪz blʌɾ ɪz ɹipleɪst wɪð sʌmθɪŋ ɛls?"

Semirhage regarded Merise, icy contempt in her voice as she spoke. "Do you know what happens to a man when his blood is replaced with something else?"

"aɪ dɪd nɑt - "

"I did not - "

"hi daɪz, ʌv kɔɹs," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛd, kʌɾɪŋ mɛɹaɪs ɔf wɪð wɝdz laɪk naɪvz. "ðə dɛθ ɔfən hæpənz ɪnstənli, ən kwɪk dɛθs ɑɹ ə lɪɾəl ɪntʃɹəst. wɪð ɪkspɛɹəmənt, aɪ dɪskʌvɝd ðət səm səluʃənz kən ɹipleɪs blʌd mɔɹ ɪfɛktɪvli, əlaʊɪŋ ðə sʌbʒɪkt tə lɪv fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm æftɝ ðə tʃɹænsfjuʒən."

"He dies, of course," Semirhage said, cutting Merise off with words like knives. "The death often happens instantly, and quick deaths are of little interest. With experiment, I discovered that some solutions can replace blood more effectively, allowing the subject to live for a short time after the transfusion."

ʃi fɛl saɪlənt.

She fell silent.

"ænsɝ ðə kwɛstʃən," mɛɹaɪs sɛd, "ɔɹ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ jəl hæŋ əɡɛn ən - "

"Answer the question," Merise said, "or out the window you will hang again and - "

"ðə tʃɹænsfjuʒən ɪtsɛlf ɹikwaɪɝz jus ə ðə paʊɝ, ʌv kɔɹs," sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɪntɝʌptɪɾ əɡɛn. "ʌðɝ mɛθədz ɑɹ nɑt kwɪk ɪnʌf. aɪ ɪnvɛntəd ðə wiv maɪsɛlf. ɪt kən sʌɾənli ən ɪnstənli pʊl ðə blʌd fɹəm ə bɑɾi ən dəpɑzɪɾ ɪɾ ɪn ə bɪn, waɪl ət ðə seɪm taɪm teɪkɪŋ ə səluʃən ən pɹɛsɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə ðə veɪnz."

"The transfusion itself requires use of the Power, of course," Semirhage interrupted again. "Other methods are not quick enough. I invented the weave myself. It can suddenly and instantly pull the blood from a body and deposit it in a bin, while at the same time taking a solution and pressing it into the veins."

mɛɹaɪs ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ, ɡlænsɪŋ ət nɛɹɪʃmə. ði æʃəmən wɔɹ ə koʊɾ ən tʃɹaʊzɝz ə blæk, əz juʒəwəl, hɪz lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ ɪn bɹeɪdz woʊvən wɪð bɛlz ɑn ði ɛnz. hi laʊnʒd əɡɛns ðə lɔɡ wɔl.

Merise gritted her teeth, glancing at Narishma. The Asha'man wore a coat and trousers of black, as usual, his long dark hair in braids woven with bells on the ends. He lounged against the log wall.

hi hæɾ ə bɔɪɪʃ feɪs, bʌt dɪspleɪɾ ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɛdʒ ə deɪnʒɝ. pɝhæps ðət keɪm fɹəm tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wɪð mɛɹaɪsəz ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz. pɝhæps ɪt keɪm fɹəm əsoʊsieɪɾɪŋ wɪð pipəl u wəd pʊt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən tə ðə kwɛstʃən.

He had a boyish face, but displayed a growing edge of danger. Perhaps that came from training with Merise's other Warders. Perhaps it came from associating with people who would put one of the Forsaken to the question.

"maɪ wɔɹnɪŋ - " mɛɹaɪs bɪɡæn əɡɛn.

"My warning - " Merise began again.

"aɪ hæd wʌn sʌbʒɪkt sɝvaɪv ən ɪntaɪɝ aʊɝ æftɝ ðə tʃɹænsfjuʒən," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛɾ ɪn ə kɑm, kɑnvɝseɪʃənəl toʊn. "aɪ kaʊn ɪɾ əz wʌn ə maɪ ɡɹeɪɾəst vɪktɝiz. hi wɑz ɪn peɪn ði ɪntaɪɝ taɪm, ʌv kɔɹs. tʃɹu peɪn, æɡəni ðəɾ i kəd fil ɪn ɛvɹi veɪn ə hɪz bɑɾi, ɹaɪt daʊn tə ðə nɪɹ-ɪnvɪzəbəl wʌnz ɪn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. aɪ noʊ ʌv noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ tə bɹɪŋ sətʃ sʌfɝɪŋ tə ɛvɹi pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɾi ət wʌns."

"I had one subject survive an entire hour after the transfusion," Semirhage said in a calm, conversational tone. "I count it as one of my greatest victories. He was in pain the entire time, of course. True pain, agony that he could feel in every vein of his body, right down to the near-invisible ones in his fingers. I know of no other way to bring such suffering to every part of the body at once."

ʃi mɛt mɛɹaɪsəz aɪz. "aɪ wɪl ʃoʊ jə ðə wiv sʌmdeɪ."

She met Merise's eyes. "I will show you the weave someday."

mɛɹaɪs peɪl dʒʌst slaɪtli.

Merise paled just slightly.

wɪð ə wɪp ə hɝ hænd, kædzueɪn woʊv ə ʃild ʌv ɛɹ ɝaʊn sɛmɝhɪdʒəz hɛd tə blɑk əɹ fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ, ðən woʊv faɪɝ ən ɛɹ ɪndə tu smɔl bɔlz ə laɪt, wɪtʃ ʃi pleɪs dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkənz aɪz. ðə laɪts wɝn bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə blaɪn əɹ dæmədʒ əɹ aɪz, bʌt ðeɪ wəd kip əɹ fɹəm siɪŋ. ðət wɑz ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ tʃɹɪk ə kædzueɪnz; tu mɛni sɪstɝz wəd θɪŋk tə dɛfən ə kæptɪv, jɛt liv əm keɪpəbəl ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ. wʌn nɛvɝ nu hu hæd lɝn tə ɹid lɪps, ən kædzueɪn hæd lɪɾəl ɪnkləneɪʃən tə ʌndɝɛstəmeɪɾ əɹ kɝən kæptɪv.

With a whip of her hand, Cadsuane wove a shield of Air around Semirhage's head to block her from hearing, then wove Fire and Air into two small balls of light, which she placed directly in front of the Forsaken's eyes. The lights weren't bright enough to blind or damage her eyes, but they would keep her from seeing. That was a particular trick of Cadsuane's; too many sisters would think to deafen a captive, yet leave them capable of watching. One never knew who had learned to read lips, and Cadsuane had little inclination to underestimate her current captive.

mɛɹaɪs ɡlænst ət kædzueɪn, ə flæʃ ʌv ənɔɪəns ɪn əɹ aɪz.

Merise glanced at Cadsuane, a flash of annoyance in her eyes.

"ju wɝ luzɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝ," kædzueɪn sɛd fɝmli, sɛɾɪŋ əɹ ti ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ tʃɛɹ.

"You were losing control of her," Cadsuane said firmly, setting her tea on the floor beside her chair.

mɛɹaɪs hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ tʃɹuli æŋɡɹi. laɪkli ət hɝsɛlf. "ðɪs wʊmən, nʌθɪŋ wɝks ɑn hɝ," ʃi sɛd. "ʃi nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒəz ðə toʊn ə hɝ vɔɪs, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt wi də tə hɝ. ɛvɹi pʌnɪʃmən aɪ kən θɪŋk ʌv oʊnli kɹieɪts mɔɹ θɹɛts. itʃ wʌn mɔɹ ɡɹusəm ðən ðə læst! laɪt!" ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ əɡɛn, ɹifoʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ən bɹiðɪŋ dipli θɹu hɝ noʊz. nɛɹɪʃmə stʃɹeɪɾənd əz ɪf tə wɔk oʊvɝ tə hɝ, bʌt ʃi weɪvd ɪm bæk. mɛɹaɪs wɑz əpɹoʊpɹiɪtli fɝm wɪð əɹ wɔɹɾɝz, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd snæp əɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls u tʃɹaɪd tə kip əm ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪsəz.

Merise hesitated, then nodded, looking truly angry. Likely at herself. "This woman, nothing works on her," she said. "She never changes the tone of her voice, no matter what we do to her. Every punishment I can think of only creates more threats. Each one more gruesome than the last! Light!" She gritted her teeth again, refolding her arms and breathing deeply through her nose. Narishma straightened as if to walk over to her, but she waved him back. Merise was appropriately firm with her Warders, though she did snap at anyone else who tried to keep them in their places.

"wi kən bɹeɪk hɝ," kædzueɪn sɛd.

"We can break her," Cadsuane said.

"kæn wi, kædzueɪn?"

"Can we, Cadsuane?"

"fɔ! ʌv kɔɹs wi kæn. ʃiz hjumən, dʒʌs laɪk ɛniwʌn ɛls."

"Phaw! Of course we can. She is human, just like anyone else."

"tʃɹu," mɛɹaɪs sɛd. "ðoʊ ʃiz lɪv fəɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz. θɹi θaʊzənd, kædzueɪn."

"True," Merise said. "Though she's lived for three thousand years. Three thousand, Cadsuane."

"ʃi spɛn ðə bʌlk ə ðət taɪm ɪmpɹɪzənd," kædzueɪn sɛd wɪð ə dɪsmɪsɪv snɪf. "sɛntʃɝiz lɑkt ʌp ɪn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, laɪkli ɪn ə tʃɹæns əɹ haɪbɝneɪʃən. səbtʃɹæk ðoʊz jɪɹz, ən ʃiz noʊ oʊldɝ ðən ɛni ʌv ʌs. ə fɛɹ saɪt jʌŋɡɝ ðən sʌm, aɪ wəɾ ɪmædʒən."

"She spent the bulk of that time imprisoned," Cadsuane said with a dismissive sniff. "Centuries locked up in the Dark One's prison, likely in a trance or hibernation. Subtract those years, and she's no older than any of us. A fair sight younger than some, I would imagine."

ɪt wɑz ə sʌɾəl ɹimaɪndɝ ə hɝ oʊn eɪdʒ, sʌmθɪŋ ɹɛɹli dɪskʌst əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ði ɪntaɪɝ kɑnvɝseɪʃən əbaʊɾ eɪdʒ wɑz, ɪn fækt, ə saɪn ə haʊ ənkʌmftəɹbəl ðə fɔɹseɪkən meɪd mɛɹaɪs. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ pɹæktəst əɾ əpɪɹɪŋ kɑm, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹizən ðət kædzueɪn hæd kɛp ðoʊz hoʊldɪŋ ðə ʃild aʊtsaɪd ðə ɹum. ðeɪ ɡeɪv əweɪ tu mʌtʃ. ivən ðə nɔɹməli ənflæpəbəl mɛɹaɪs lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl fɑɹ tu ɔfən dʊɹɪŋ ðiz ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃənz.

It was a subtle reminder of her own age, something rarely discussed among Aes Sedai. The entire conversation about age was, in fact, a sign of how uncomfortable the Forsaken made Merise. Aes Sedai were practiced at appearing calm, but there was a reason that Cadsuane had kept those holding the shield outside the room. They gave away too much. Even the normally unflappable Merise lost control far too often during these interrogations.

ʌv kɔɹs, mɛɹaɪs ən ði ʌðɝz - laɪk ɔl ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ ðiz deɪz - stɪl fɛl ʃɔɹɾ ʌv wʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃəd bi. ðiz jʌŋɡɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn əlaʊd tə ɡɹoʊ sɑft ən wik, pɹoʊn tə bɪkɝɪŋ. səm hæɾ əlaʊd ðɛmsɛlvz tə bi bʊliɾ ɪndə swɛɹɪŋ fiəlti tə ɹænd ælθɹ.

Of course, Merise and the others - like all the women in the Tower these days - still fell short of what an Aes Sedai should be. These younger Aes Sedai had been allowed to grow soft and weak, prone to bickering. Some had allowed themselves to be bullied into swearing fealty to Rand al'Thor.

səmtaɪmz, kædzueɪn wɪʃt ʃi kəd sɪmpli sɛn əm ɔl tə pɛnəns fəɹ ə fju dɛkeɪdz.

Sometimes, Cadsuane wished she could simply send them all to penance for a few decades.

əɹ meɪbi ðət wɑz dʒʌs kædzueɪnz eɪdʒ spikɪŋ. ʃi wɑz oʊld, ən ðət wɑz meɪkɪŋ əɹ ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɪntɑlɝən ə fulɪʃnəs. oʊvɝ tu sɛntʃɝiz əɡoʊ, ʃid swɔɹn tə hɝsɛlf ðət ʃid lɪv tə ətɛn ðə læs bæɾəl, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ lɔŋ ðət tʊk. juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ lɛŋθənd wʌnz jɪɹz, ən ʃid faʊn ðət dɪtɝməneɪʃən ən ɡɹɪt kəd stʃɹɛtʃ ðoʊz jɪɹz ivən fɝðɝ. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ði oʊldəs pipəl əlaɪv.

Or maybe that was just Cadsuane's age speaking. She was old, and that was making her increasingly intolerant of foolishness. Over two centuries ago, she'd sworn to herself that she'd live to attend the Last Battle, no matter how long that took. Using the One Power lengthened one's years, and she'd found that determination and grit could stretch those years even further. She was one of the oldest people alive.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, hɝ jɪɹz hæd tɔɾ əɹ ðət noʊ mɛʒɝ ə plænɪŋ əɹ dɪtɝməneɪʃən kəd meɪk laɪf tɝn aʊɾ əz jə wɑntəd. ðət dɪdn stɑp əɹ fɹəm biɪŋ ənɔɪd wən ɪt dɪdnt. wʌn maɪɾ əv θɔt ðət ðə jɪɹz wəɾ ɔlsoʊ hæv tɔɾ əɹ peɪʃəns, bʌɾ ɪt hæd dʌn ði ɑpəzət. ði oʊldɝ ʃi ɡɹu, ðə lɛs ɪnklaɪnd ʃi wɑz tə weɪt, fəɹ ʃi nu ʃi dɪdn əv mɛni jɪɹz lɛft.

Unfortunately, her years had taught her that no measure of planning or determination could make life turn out as you wanted. That didn't stop her from being annoyed when it didn't. One might have thought that the years would also have taught her patience, but it had done the opposite. The older she grew, the less inclined she was to wait, for she knew she didn't have many years left.

ɛniwʌn u kleɪm ðəɾ oʊld eɪdʒ hæd bɹɔɾ əm peɪʃəns wɑz iðɝ laɪɪŋ əɹ sinaɪl.

Anyone who claimed that old age had brought them patience was either lying or senile.

"ʃi kən ən wɪl bi bɹoʊkən," kædzueɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd, "aɪ æm nɑt gɑnə əlaʊ ə pɝsən u noʊz wivz fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz tə sɪmpli dæns hɝsɛlf tə ɛksəkjuʃən. wəɹ gɑnə pʊl ɛvɹi skɹæp ə nɑlədʒ fɹəm ðət wʊmənz bɹeɪn, ɪf wɪv tə tɝn ə fju ʌv əɹ oʊn 'kɹieɪɾɪv' wivz ɑn hɝ."

"She can and will be broken," Cadsuane repeated, "I am not going to allow a person who knows weaves from the Age of Legends to simply dance herself to execution. We are going to pull every scrap of knowledge from that woman's brain, if we have to turn a few of her own 'creative' weaves on her."

"ði æɾəm. ɪf oʊnli ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wəd lɛɾ əs juz ɪɾ ɑn əɹ . . ." mɛɹaɪs sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət sɛmɝhɪdʒ.

"The a'dam. If only the Lord Dragon would let us use it on her . . ." Merise said, glancing at Semirhage.

ɪf ɛvɝ kædzueɪn hæd bɪn tɛmptəd tə bɹeɪk əɹ wɝd, ɪt wɑz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðæt. slɪp ən æɾəm ɑn ðə wʊmən . . . bʌt noʊ, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə fɔɹs sʌmwʌn tə tɔk wɪð ən æɾəm, jə hæd tə ɡɪv əm peɪn. ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm əz tɔɹtʃɝ, ən ælθɹ hæd fɔɹbɪɾən ɪt.

If ever Cadsuane had been tempted to break her word, it was regarding that. Slip an a'dam on the woman . . . but no, in order to force someone to talk with an a'dam, you had to give them pain. It was the same as torture, and al'Thor had forbidden it.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd kloʊzd əɹ aɪz əɡɛns kædzueɪnz laɪts, bʌt ʃi wɑz stɪl kəmpoʊzd, kəntʃɹoʊld.

Semirhage had closed her eyes against Cadsuane's lights, but she was still composed, controlled.

wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðət wʊmənz maɪnd? dɪd ʃi weɪt fəɹ ɹɛskju? dɪd ʃi θɪŋk tə fɔɹs əm tə ɛksəkjuɾ əɹ soʊ ðət ʃi kəɾ əvɔɪd tʃɹu tɔɹtʃɝ? dɪd ʃi ɹɪli əsum ðət ʃid bi eɪbəl tə ɪskeɪp, ðən ɹik vɛnʒəns ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd kwɛstʃən hɝ?

What was going on in that woman's mind? Did she wait for rescue? Did she think to force them to execute her so that she could avoid true torture? Did she really assume that she'd be able to escape, then wreak vengeance on the Aes Sedai who had questioned her?

laɪkli ðə læst - ən ɪt wɑz hɑɹd nɑt tə fil ət list ə hɪn ʌv æpɹɪhɛnʃən. ðə wʊmən nu θɪŋz əbaʊt ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðət hædn sɝvaɪvd ivən ɪn lɛdʒənz. θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz wɑz ə lɔŋ, lɔŋ taɪm. kəd sɛmɝhɪdʒ bɹeɪk θɹu ə ʃild ɪn ə weɪ ðət wɑz ənnoʊn? ɪf ʃi kʊd, waɪ hædnt ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi? kædzueɪn wʊdn bi ɪntaɪɝli kʌmftəɹbəl əntɪl ʃi wɑz eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ əɹ hænz ɑn səm ə ðət fɔkɹut ti.

Likely the last - and it was hard not to feel at least a hint of apprehension. The woman knew things about the One Power that hadn't survived even in legends. Three thousand years was a long, long time. Could Semirhage break through a shield in a way that was unknown? If she could, why hadn't she already? Cadsuane wouldn't be entirely comfortable until she was able to get her hands on some of that forkroot tea.

"jɔɹ wivz, jə kən ɹilis ðɛm, kædzueɪn," mɛɹaɪs sɛd, stændɪŋ. "aɪ hæv kəmpoʊz maɪsɛlf. aɪ fɪɹ wɪl əv tə hæŋ əɹ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ fəɹ ə taɪm, əz aɪ sɛd. pɝhæps wi kən θɹɛɾən əɹ wɪð peɪn. ʃi kænt noʊ ʌv ælθɹz fulɪʃ ɹɪkwaɪɹməns."

"Your weaves, you can release them, Cadsuane," Merise said, standing. "I have composed myself. I fear we will have to hang her out the window for a time, as I said. Perhaps we can threaten her with pain. She can't know of al'Thor's foolish requirements."

kædzueɪn lin fɔɹwɝd, ɹilisɪŋ ðə wivz ðət hʌŋ ðə laɪts bɪfɔɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkənz aɪz, bʌt nɑt ɹimuvɪŋ ðə ʃild ʌv ɛɹ ðət kɛpt əɹ fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ. sɛmɝhɪdʒəz aɪz snæpt oʊpən, ðən kwɪkli faʊn kædzueɪn. jɛs, ʃi nu hu wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ. ðə tu lɑkt aɪz.

Cadsuane leaned forward, releasing the weaves that hung the lights before the Forsaken's eyes, but not removing the shield of Air that kept her from hearing. Semirhage's eyes snapped open, then quickly found Cadsuane. Yes, she knew who was in charge. The two locked eyes.

mɛɹaɪs kəntɪnjud tə kwɛstʃən, æskɪŋ əbaʊt ɡɹeɪndəl. ælθɹ θɔt ði ʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən maɪt bi sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ɑɹæd dumən. kædzueɪn wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ʌðɝ kwɛstʃənz, bʌt ɡɹeɪndəl meɪɾ ən æksɛptəbəl stɑɹɾɪŋ pɔɪnt.

Merise continued to question, asking about Graendal. Al'Thor thought the other Forsaken might be somewhere in Arad Doman. Cadsuane was far more interested in other questions, but Graendal made an acceptable starting point.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɹɪspɑndɪd tə mɛɹaɪsəz kwɛstʃənz wɪð saɪləns ðɪs taɪm, ən kædzueɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ælθɹ. ðə bɔɪ hæd ɹɪzɪstɪɾ əɹ titʃɪŋ əz stʌbɝnli əz sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɹɪzɪstɪd kwɛstʃənɪŋ. oʊ, tʃɹu, hi hæd lɝn səm maɪnɝ θɪŋz - haʊ tə tʃɹiɾ əɹ wɪð ə mɛʒɝ ə ɹɪspɛkt, haʊ tə ət lis feɪn səvɪləɾi. bʌt nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ.

Semirhage responded to Merise's questions with silence this time, and Cadsuane found herself thinking about al'Thor. The boy had resisted her teaching as stubbornly as Semirhage resisted questioning. Oh, true, he had learned some minor things - how to treat her with a measure of respect, how to at least feign civility. But nothing more.

kædzueɪn heɪɾəd ædmɪɾɪŋ feɪljɝ. ən ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə feɪljɝ, nɑt jɛt, bʌt ʃi wɑz kloʊs. ðət bɔɪ wɑz dɛstɪn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə wɝld. ən meɪbi seɪv ɪt, tu. ðə fɝst wɑz ɪnɛvəɾəbəl; ðə sɛkən kəndɪʃənəl. ʃi kəd wɪʃ ðə tu wɝ ɹɪvɝst, bʌt wɪʃɪz wɝ əbaʊɾ əz jusfəl əz kɔɪnz kɑɹv fɹəm wʊd. jə kəd peɪn əm haʊɛvɝ jə wɑntəd, bʌt ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪnd wʊd.

Cadsuane hated admitting failure. And this was not a failure, not yet, but she was close. That boy was destined to destroy the world. And maybe save it, too. The first was inevitable; the second conditional. She could wish the two were reversed, but wishes were about as useful as coins carved from wood. You could paint them however you wanted, but they remained wood.

ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ, pʊɾɪŋ ðə bɔɪ aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪnd. ʃi niɾəd tə wɑtʃ sɛmɝhɪdʒ. itʃ taɪm ðə wʊmən spoʊk, ɪt kəd bi ə klu. sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɹɪtɝn əɹ stɛɹ, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ mɛɹaɪs.

She gritted her teeth, putting the boy out of her mind. She needed to watch Semirhage. Each time the woman spoke, it could be a clue. Semirhage returned her stare, ignoring Merise.

haʊ dɪd jə bɹeɪk wʌn ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wɪmən u hæɾ ɛvɝ lɪvd? ə wʊmən u hæd pɝpətʃɹeɪɾɪd kaʊnləs ətʃɹɑsəɾiz dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪz ʌv wʌndɝ bɪfɔɹ, ivən, ðə dɑɹk wʌnz ɹilis?

How did you break one of the most powerful women who had ever lived? A woman who had perpetrated countless atrocities during the days of wonder before, even, the Dark One's release?

miɾɪŋ ðoʊz blæk, ɑnɪks aɪz, kædzueɪn ɹilaɪz sʌmθɪŋ. ælθɹz pɹoʊəbɪʃən ɑn hɝɾɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz minɪŋləs. ðeɪ kəd nɑt bɹeɪk ðɪs wʊmən wɪð peɪn. sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz ðə ɡɹeɪt tɔɹtʃɝɝ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ə wʊmən ɪntʃɹiɡd baɪ dɛθ ən æɡəni.

Meeting those black, onyx eyes, Cadsuane realized something. Al'Thor's prohibition on hurting Semirhage was meaningless. They could not break this woman with pain. Semirhage was the great torturer of the Forsaken, a woman intrigued by death and agony.

noʊ, ʃi wəd nɑt bɹeɪk ðət weɪ, ivən ɪf ðə minz hæd bɪn əlaʊd ðɛm. wɪð ə tʃɪl, lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðoʊz aɪz, kædzueɪn θɔt ʃi sɔ sʌmθɪŋ ə hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə kɹitʃɝ. eɪdʒ, kɹæftinəs ən ənwɪlɪŋnɪs tə bʌdʒ.

No, she would not break that way, even if the means had been allowed them. With a chill, looking into those eyes, Cadsuane thought she saw something of herself in the creature. Age, craftiness and unwillingness to budge.

ðæt, ðɛn, lɛft ə kwɛstʃən fəɹ hɝ. ɪf ɡɪvən ðə tæsk, haʊ wəd kædzueɪn ɡoʊ əbaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ hɝsɛlf?

That, then, left a question for her. If given the task, how would Cadsuane go about breaking herself?

ðə kɑnsɛpt wɑz soʊ dɪstɝbɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz ɹɪlivd wən kɔɹəl ɪntɝʌptɪd ði ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃən ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ. ðə slɛndɝ, tʃɪɹfəl mʊɹændiən wɑz lɔɪəl tə kædzueɪn ən hæd bɪn ɑn duɾi wɑtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ælθɹ ðɪs æftɝnun. kɔɹəlz wɝd ðəɾ ælθɹ wəd bi miɾɪŋ sun wɪð ɪz il tʃifs bɹɔɾ ən ɛn tə ði ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃən, ən ðə θɹi sɪstɝz meɪnteɪnɪŋ ðə ʃild ɛntɝɾ ən toʊd sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɔf tə ðə ɹum wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd sɛɾ əɹ baʊn ən ɡæɡd wɪð floʊz ʌv ɛɹ.

The concept was so disturbing that she was relieved when Corele interrupted the interrogation a few moments later. The slender, cheerful Murandian was loyal to Cadsuane and had been on duty watching over al'Thor this afternoon. Corele's word that al'Thor would be meeting soon with his Aiel chiefs brought an end to the interrogation, and the three sisters maintaining the shield entered and towed Semirhage off to the room where they would set her bound and gagged with flows of Air.

kædzueɪn wɑtʃt ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɡoʊ, kæɹiɾ ɑn wivz ʌv ɛɹ, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd bɪn oʊnli ðə deɪz oʊpənɪŋ sin. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə dil wɪð ðə bɔɪ.

Cadsuane watched the Forsaken go, carried on weaves of Air, then shook her head. Semirhage had been only the day's opening scene. It was time to deal with the boy.

tʃæptɝ sɪks

CHAPTER 6

wən aɪɝn mɛls ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi hæd sin ə lɑɾ ə bæɾəlfildz. səm θɪŋz wɝ ɔlweɪz ðə seɪm. dɛd mɛn laɪk paɪlz ə ɹæɡz, laɪɪŋ ɪn hips. ɹeɪvənz iɡɝ tə daɪn. ɡɹoʊnz, kɹaɪz, wɪmpɝz ən mʌmbəlz fɹəm ðoʊz ənlʌki ɪnʌf tə niɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm tə daɪ.

When Iron Melts Rodel Ituralde had seen a lot of battlefields. Some things were always the same. Dead men like piles of rags, lying in heaps. Ravens eager to dine. Groans, cries, whimpers and mumbles from those unlucky enough to need a long time to die.

itʃ bæɾəlfild ɔlsoʊ hæɾ ɪts oʊn ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl pɹɪnt. jə kəd ɹiɾ ə bæɾəl laɪk ðə tʃɹeɪl ə pæsɪŋ ɡeɪm. kɔɹpsəz laɪɪŋ ɪn ɹoʊz ðət wɝ dɪstɝbɪŋli stʃɹeɪɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ə tʃɑɹdʒ ə fʊtmən u hæd bɪn pɹɛst əɡɛns vɑliz ʌv æɹoʊz. skæɾɝd ən tʃɹæmpəl bɑɾiz wɝ ðə ɹɪzʌlt ʌv ɪnfəntʃɹi bɹeɪkɪŋ bɪfɔɹ hɛvi kævəlɹi. ðɪs bæɾəl hæd sin lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə sintʃæn kɹʌʃt ʌp əɡɛns ðə wɔlz ə dɑɹlunə, wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd fɔt wɪð dɛspɝeɪʃən. hæmɝɾ əɡɛns ðə stoʊn. wʌn sɛkʃən ʌv wɔl wɑz kəmplitli tɔɹn əweɪ wɛɹ səm deɪmeɪn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪskeɪp ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. faɪɾɪŋ ɪn stʃɹits ən əmʌŋ hoʊmz wʊɾə feɪvɝd ðə sintʃæn. ðeɪ hædn meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪn taɪm.

Each battlefield also had its own individual print. You could read a battle like the trail of passing game. Corpses lying in rows that were disturbingly straight indicated a charge of footmen who had been pressed against volleys of arrows. Scattered and trampled bodies were the result of infantry breaking before heavy cavalry. This battle had seen large numbers of Seanchan crushed up against the walls of Darluna, where they had fought with desperation. Hammered against the stone. One section of wall was completely torn away where some damane had tried to escape into the city. Fighting in streets and among homes would have favored the Seanchan. They hadn't made it in time.

ɪɾɝɑldi ɹoʊɾ ɪz ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋ θɹu ðə mɛs. bæɾəl wɑz ɔlweɪz ə mɛs. ði oʊnli nit bæɾəlz wɝ ðə wʌnz ɪn stɔɹiz əɹ hɪstɝi bʊks. ðoʊz hæd bɪn klɛnzd ən skaʊɝd baɪ ði əbɹeɪsɪv hænz ə skɑlɝz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ kənsəsnəs. "əɡɹɛsɝ wʌn, fɪfti-θɹi θaʊzən kɪld" əɹ "dɪfɛndɝ stʊd, twɛnti θaʊzən fɔlən."

Ituralde rode his roan gelding through the mess. Battle was always a mess. The only neat battles were the ones in stories or history books. Those had been cleansed and scoured by the abrasive hands of scholars looking for conciseness. "Aggressor won, fifty-three thousand killed" or "Defender stood, twenty thousand fallen."

wʌt wəd bi ɹɪɾən ə ðɪs bæɾəl? ɪt wəd dɪpɛn ɑn u wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ. ðeɪ wəd nəɡlɛk tə ɪnklud ðə blʌd, paʊndɪɾ ɪndə ði ɝθ tə meɪk mʌd. ðə bɑɾiz, bɹoʊkən, pɪɹst ən mæŋɡəld. ðə ɡɹaʊn tɔɹn ɪn swɑθs baɪ ɛnɹeɪdʒ deɪmeɪn. pɝhæps ðeɪ wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə nʌmbɝz; ðoʊz ɔfən simd ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə skɹaɪbz. hæf ʌv ɪɾɝɑldiz hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd, dɛd. ɑn ɛni ʌðɝ bæɾəlfild, fɪfti θaʊzən kæʒəwəltiz wʊɾə ʃeɪmd ən æŋɡɝd hɪm. bʌt hid feɪs daʊn ə fɔɹs θɹi taɪmz ɪz saɪz, ən wʌn wɪð deɪmeɪn ət ðæt.

What would be written of this battle? It would depend on who was writing. They would neglect to include the blood, pounded into the earth to make mud. The bodies, broken, pierced and mangled. The ground torn in swaths by enraged damane. Perhaps they would remember the numbers; those often seemed important to scribes. Half of Ituralde's hundred thousand, dead. On any other battlefield, fifty thousand casualties would have shamed and angered him. But he'd faced down a force three times his size, and one with damane at that.

hi fɑloʊd ðə jʌŋ mɛsənʒɝ u hæd fɛtʃt hɪm, ə bɔɪ ʌv pɝhæps twɛlv, wɛɹɪŋ ə sintʃæn junəfɔɹm ə ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin. ðeɪ pæst ə fɔlən stændɝd, hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ə bɹoʊkən poʊl wɪð ðə tɪp dʒɹɪvən ɪndə mʌd. ɪt bɔɹ ðə saɪn ʌv ə sʌn biɪŋ kɹɔs baɪ sɪks ɡʌlz. ɪɾɝɑldi heɪɾəd nɑt noʊɪŋ ðə haʊsəz ən neɪmz ə ðə mɛn i wɑz faɪɾɪŋ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl wɪð ðə fɔɹən sintʃæn.

He followed the young messenger who had fetched him, a boy of perhaps twelve, wearing a Seanchan uniform of red and green. They passed a fallen standard, hanging from a broken pole with the tip driven into mud. It bore the sign of a sun being crossed by six gulls. Ituralde hated not knowing the houses and names of the men he was fighting, but there was no way to tell with the foreign Seanchan.

ðə ʃædoʊz kæs baɪ ə daɪɪŋ ivnɪŋ sʌn stʃɹaɪp ðə fild. sun ə blæŋkəɾ ə dɑɹknəs wəd kɹeɪɾəl ðə bɑɾiz, ən ðə sɝvaɪvɝz kəd pɹitɛn fəɹ ə taɪm ðət ðə ɡɹæslænd wɑz ə ɡɹeɪv fəɹ ðɛɹ fɹɛnz. ən fəɹ ðə pipəl ðɛɹ fɹɛnz hæd kɪld. hi ɹaʊndəɾ ə smɔl hɪlək, kʌmɪŋ tə ə skæɾɝd pæɾɝn ə fɔlən sintʃæn ɪlit. moʊst ə ðiz dɛd wɔɹ ðoʊz ɪnsɛktlaɪk hɛlmz. bɛnt, kɹækt, əɹ dɛntɪd. dɛɾ aɪz stɛɹd blæŋkli fɹəm oʊpənɪŋz bɪhaɪn twɪstəd mændəbəlz.

The shadows cast by a dying evening sun striped the field. Soon a blanket of darkness would cradle the bodies, and the survivors could pretend for a time that the grassland was a grave for their friends. And for the people their friends had killed. He rounded a small hillock, coming to a scattered pattern of fallen Seanchan elite. Most of these dead wore those insectlike helms. Bent, cracked, or dented. Dead eyes stared blankly from openings behind twisted mandibles.

ðə sintʃæn dʒɛnɝəl wɑz əlaɪv, ɪf dʒʌs bɛɹli. hɪz hɛlmət wɑz ɔf, ən ðəɹ wɑz blʌɾ ɑn ɪz lɪps. hi lin əɡɛnst ə lɑɹdʒ, mɔs-kʌvɝd boʊldɝ, bæk səpɔɹɾəd baɪ ə bʌndəl kloʊk, əz ɪf i wɝ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə mil tə bi dɪlɪvɝd. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɾ ɪmədʒ wɑz mɑɹd baɪ hɪz twɪstəd lɛɡ ən ðə bɹoʊkən hæft ʌv ə spɪɹ pʌntʃɪŋ θɹu ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz stʌmək.

The Seanchan general was alive, if just barely. His helmet was off, and there was blood on his lips. He leaned against a large, moss-covered boulder, back supported by a bundled cloak, as if he were waiting for a meal to be delivered. Of course, that image was marred by his twisted leg and the broken haft of a spear punching through the front of his stomach.

ɪɾɝɑldi dɪsmaʊntɪd. laɪk moʊst ə hɪz mɛn, ɪɾɝɑldi wɔɹ wɝkɝz kloʊðɪŋ - sɪmpəl bɹaʊn tʃɹaʊzɝz ən koʊt, bɑɹoʊɾ ɔf ə ðə mæn u hæd teɪkən ɪɾɝɑldiz junəfɔɹm əz pɑɹɾ ə ðə tʃɹæp.

Ituralde dismounted. Like most of his men, Ituralde wore worker's clothing - simple brown trousers and coat, borrowed off of the man who had taken Ituralde's uniform as part of the trap.

ɪt fɛlt ɑd tə bi aʊɾ ə junəfɔɹm. ə mæn laɪk ðɪs dʒɛnɝəl tʃɹən dɪd nɑt dɪzɝv ə soʊlʒɝ ɪn dʒɹæb.

It felt odd to be out of uniform. A man like this General Turan did not deserve a soldier in drab.

ɪɾɝɑldi weɪv ðə mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪ tə stæn bæk, aʊɾ ʌv ɪɹʃɑt, ðən əpɹoʊtʃt ðə sintʃæn əloʊn.

Ituralde waved the messenger boy to stand back, out of earshot, then approached the Seanchan alone.

"jɔɹ hɪm, ðɛn," tʃɹən sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪɾɝɑldi, spikɪŋ wɪð ðət sloʊ sintʃæn dʒɹɔl.

"You're him, then," Turan said, looking up at Ituralde, speaking with that slow Seanchan drawl.

hi wɑz ə staʊt mæn, fɑɹ fɹəm tɔl, wɪð ə pik noʊz. hɪz kloʊs-kɹɑp blæk hɛɹ wɑz ʃeɪv tu fɪŋɡɝ wɪdθs ʌp itʃ saɪɾ ə hɪz hɛd, ən ɪz hɛlm leɪ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bɛɹɪŋ θɹi waɪt plumz. hi ɹitʃt ʌp wɪð ən ənstɛɾi blæk-ɡlʌv hæn ən waɪp ðə blʌd fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz maʊθ.

He was a stout man, far from tall, with a peaked nose. His close-cropped black hair was shaved two finger widths up each side of his head, and his helm lay beside him on the ground, bearing three white plumes. He reached up with an unsteady black-gloved hand and wiped the blood from the corner of his mouth.

"aɪ æm," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd.

"I am," Ituralde said.

"ðeɪ kɔl jə ə 'ɡɹeɪt kæptən' ɪn tæɹɑbən."

"They call you a 'Great Captain' in Tarabon."

"ðeɪ du."

"They do."

"ɪts dɪzɝvd," tʃɹən sɛd, kɑfɪŋ. "haʊ dɪd jə də ɪt? əɹ skaʊts. . . ." hɪz kɑf kənsum hɪm.

"It's deserved," Turan said, coughing. "How did you do it? Our scouts. . . ." His cough consumed him.

"ɹeɪkən," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd wʌns ðə kɑf səbsaɪɾɪd. hi skwɑɾɪd daʊn bɪsaɪɾ ɪz foʊ. ðə sʌn wɑz stɪl ə slɪvɝ ɪn ðə wɛst, laɪɾɪŋ ðə bæɾəlfild wɪð ə ɡlɪmɝ ʌv ɡoʊldən ɹɛd laɪt. "jɔɹ skaʊts si fɹəm ði ɛɹ, ən tʃɹuθ ɪz izi tə haɪd fɹəm ə dɪstəns."

"Raken," Ituralde said once the cough subsided. He squatted down beside his foe. The sun was still a sliver in the west, lighting the battlefield with a glimmer of golden red light. "Your scouts see from the air, and truth is easy to hide from a distance."

"ði ɑɹmi bɪhaɪn ʌs?"

"The army behind us?"

"wɪmən ən juðz, moʊsli," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə fɑɹmɝz əz wɛl. wɛɹɪŋ junəfɔɹmz teɪkən fɹəm maɪ tʃɹups hɪɹ."

"Women and youths, mostly," Ituralde said. "A fair number of farmers as well. Wearing uniforms taken from my troops here."

"æn ɪf wid tɝn ən ətækt?"

"And if we'd turned and attacked?"

"ju wʊdn hæv. jəɹ ɹeɪkən toʊl jə ðət jə wɝ aʊtnʌmbɝd. bɛɾɝ tə tʃeɪs æftɝ ðə smɔlɝ fɔɹs əhɛɾ ə ju. bɛɾɝ ðən ðət tə hɛd fəɹ ðə sɪɾi jəɹ skaʊts seɪ ɪz bɛɹli dɪfɛndəd, ivən ɪf ɪt minz mɑɹtʃɪŋ jəɹ mɛn nɪɹ tə ɪɡzɔstʃən."

"You wouldn't have. Your raken told you that you were outnumbered. Better to chase after the smaller force ahead of you. Better than that to head for the city your scouts say is barely defended, even if it means marching your men near to exhaustion."

tʃɹən kɔft əɡɛn, nɑɾɪŋ. "jɛs. jɛs, bʌt ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɛmpti. haʊ dɪd jə ɡɛt tʃɹups ɪndə ɪt?"

Turan coughed again, nodding. "Yes. Yes, but the city was empty. How did you get troops into it?"

"skaʊts ɪn ði ɛɹ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, "kæn si ɪnsaɪd bɪldɪŋz."

"Scouts in the air," Ituralde said, "can't see inside buildings."

"ju ɔɹɾɝd jəɹ tʃɹups tə haɪɾ ɪnsaɪd fəɹ ðət lɔŋ?"

"You ordered your troops to hide inside for that long?"

"jɛs," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "wɪð ə ɹoʊteɪʃən əlaʊɪŋ ə smɔl nʌmbɝ aʊɾ itʃ deɪ tə wɝk ðə filz."

"Yes," Ituralde said. "With a rotation allowing a small number out each day to work the fields."

tʃɹən ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. "ju ɹilaɪz wʌt juv dʌn," hi sɛd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ θɹɛɾ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. ɪn fækt, ðəɹ wɑz ə fɛɹ əmaʊn ʌv ædmɝeɪʃən. "haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ wɪl nɛvɝ æksɛp ðɪs feɪljɝ. ʃɪl əv tə bɹeɪk jə naʊ, ɪf oʊnli tə seɪv feɪs."

Turan shook his head in disbelief. "You realize what you have done," he said. There was no threat in his voice. In fact, there was a fair amount of admiration. "High Lady Suroth will never accept this failure. She will have to break you now, if only to save face."

"aɪ noʊ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, stændɪŋ. "bʌɾ aɪ kæn dʒɹaɪv jə bæk baɪ ətækɪŋ jə ɪn jəɹ fɔɹtʃɹəsəz. aɪ nid jə tə kʌm tə mi."

"I know," Ituralde said, standing. "But I can't drive you back by attacking you in your fortresses. I need you to come to me."

"ju doʊn ʌndɝstæn ðə nʌmbɝz wɪv . . ." tʃɹən sɛd. "wʌt jə dɪstʃɹɔɪd tədeɪ ɪz bʌɾ ə bɹiz kəmpɛɹd tə ðə stɔɹm juv ɹeɪzd. ɪnʌf ə maɪ pipəl ɪskeɪp tədeɪ tə tɛl ə jəɹ tʃɹɪks. ðəl nɑt wɝk əɡɛn."

"You don't understand the numbers we have . . ." Turan said. "What you destroyed today is but a breeze compared to the storm you've raised. Enough of my people escaped today to tell of your tricks. They will not work again."

hi wɑz ɹaɪt. ðə sintʃæn lɝn kwɪkli. ɪɾɝɑldi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə kʌt ʃɔɹɾ ɪz ɹeɪdz ɪn tæɹɑbən kəz ə ðə swɪf sintʃæn ɹiækʃən.

He was right. The Seanchan learned quickly. Ituralde had been forced to cut short his raids in Tarabon because of the swift Seanchan reaction.

"ju noʊ jə kæn biɾ ʌs," tʃɹən sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ si ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ aɪz, ɡɹeɪt kæptən."

"You know you can't beat us," Turan said softly. "I see it in your eyes, Great Captain."

ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd.

Ituralde nodded.

"waɪ, ðɛn?" tʃɹən æskt.

"Why, then?" Turan asked.

"waɪ dʌz ə kɹoʊ flaɪ?" ɪɾɝɑldi æskt.

"Why does a crow fly?" Ituralde asked.

tʃɹən kɔft wikli.

Turan coughed weakly.

ɪɾɝɑldi dɪd noʊ ðəɾ i kəd nɑt wɪn ɪz wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn. ɑdli, itʃ ə hɪz vɪktɝiz meɪɾ ɪm mɔɹ sɝɾən ə hɪz əvɛntʃuəl feɪljɝ. ðə sintʃæn wɝ smɑɹt, wɛl ɪkwɪpt ən wɛl dɪsəplənd. mɔɹ ðən ðæt, ðeɪ wɝ pɝsɪstənt.

Ituralde did know that he could not win his war against the Seanchan. Oddly, each of his victories made him more certain of his eventual failure. The Seanchan were smart, well equipped and well disciplined. More than that, they were persistent.

tʃɹən hɪmsɛlf mʌst əv noʊn fɹəm ðə moʊmən ðoʊz ɡeɪts oʊpən ðəɾ i wɑz dumd. bʌɾ i hæd nɑt sɝɛndɝd; hi hæd fɔɾ əntɪl ɪz ɑɹmi bɹoʊk, skæɾɝɪŋ ɪn tu mɛni dɝɛkʃənz fəɹ ɪɾɝɑldiz ɪɡzɔstəd tʃɹups tə kætʃ. tʃɹən ʌndɝstʊd. səmtaɪmz, sɝɛndɝ wɑznt wɝθ ðə kɑst.

Turan himself must have known from the moment those gates opened that he was doomed. But he had not surrendered; he had fought until his army broke, scattering in too many directions for Ituralde's exhausted troops to catch. Turan understood. Sometimes, surrender wasn't worth the cost.

noʊ mæn wɛlkəm dɛθ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ fɑɹ wɝs ɛnz fəɹ ə soʊlʒɝ. əbændənɪŋ wʌnz hoʊmlæn tə ɪnveɪɾɝz . . . wɛl, ɪɾɝɑldi kʊdn də ðæt. nɑɾ ivən ɪf ðə faɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə wɪn.

No man welcomed death, but there were far worse ends for a soldier. Abandoning one's homeland to invaders . . . well, Ituralde couldn't do that. Not even if the fight was impossible to win.

hi dɪd wʌt niɾəd tə bi dʌn, wən ɪt niɾəd tə bi dʌn. ən ɹaɪt naʊ, ɑɹæd dumən niɾəd tə faɪt. ðeɪ wəd luz, bʌt ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən wəɾ ɔlweɪz noʊ ðət ðɛɹ fɑðɝz hæd ɹɪzɪstɪd. ðət ɹɪzɪstəns wəd bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, wən ə ɹɪbɛljən keɪm. ɪf wʌn keɪm.

He did what needed to be done, when it needed to be done. And right now, Arad Doman needed to fight. They would lose, but their children would always know that their fathers had resisted. That resistance would be important in a hundred years, when a rebellion came. If one came.

ɪɾɝɑldi stʊɾ ʌp, ɪntɛndɪŋ tə ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz weɪɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝz.

Ituralde stood up, intending to return to his waiting soldiers.

tʃɹən stʃɹʌɡəld, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd. ɪɾɝɑldi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, tɝnɪŋ bæk.

Turan struggled, reaching for his sword. Ituralde hesitated, turning back.

"wɪl jə də ɪt?" tʃɹən æskt.

"Will you do it?" Turan asked.

ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd, ənʃiðɪŋ ɪz oʊn sɔɹd.

Ituralde nodded, unsheathing his own sword.

"ɪɾ əz bɪn ən ɑnɝ," tʃɹən sɛd, ðən kloʊzd ɪz aɪz. ɪɾɝɑldiz sɔɹd - hɛɹən-mɑɹkt - tʊk ðə mænz hɛɾ ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ. tʃɹənz oʊn bleɪd bɔɹ ə hɛɹən, bɛɹli vɪzəbəl ɑn ðə ɡlimɪŋ lɛŋθ ə bleɪd ðə sintʃæn hæd mænədʒ tə pʊl. ɪt wɑz ə pɪɾi ðət ðə tu ʌv əm hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə kɹɔs sɔɹdz - ðoʊ, ɪn ə weɪ, ðiz pæs fju wiks hæd bɪn dʒʌs ðæt, ɑn ə dɪfɹən skeɪl.

"It has been an honor," Turan said, then closed his eyes. Ituralde's sword - heron-marked - took the man's head a moment later. Turan's own blade bore a heron, barely visible on the gleaming length of blade the Seanchan had managed to pull. It was a pity that the two of them hadn't been able to cross swords - though, in a way, these past few weeks had been just that, on a different scale.

ɪɾɝɑldi klin ɪz sɔɹd, ðən slɪɾ ɪt bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ. ɪn ə faɪnəl dʒɛstʃɝ, hi slɪd tʃɹənz sɔɹɾ aʊɾ ən ɹæmd ɪɾ ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd ðə fɔlən dʒɛnɝəl. ɪɾɝɑldi ðən ɹimaʊntɪɾ ænd, nɑɾɪŋ fɛɹwɛl tə ðə mɛsənʒɝ, meɪɾ ɪz weɪ bæk əkɹɔs ðə ʃæɾoʊd fild ə kɔɹpsəz.

Ituralde cleaned his sword, then slid it back into its sheath. In a final gesture, he slid Turan's sword out and rammed it into the ground beside the fallen general. Ituralde then remounted and, nodding farewell to the messenger, made his way back across the shadowed field of corpses.

ðə ɹeɪvənz hæd bɪɡʌn.

The ravens had begun.

"aɪv tʃɹaɪɾ ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ sɛvɹəl ə ðə sɝvɪŋ mɛn ən taʊɝ ɡɑɹdz," lin sɛd sɔfli, sɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə bɑɹz ə hɝ sɛl. "bʌɾ ɪts hɑɹd." ʃi smaɪld, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin, hu sæɾ ɑn ə stul aʊtsaɪd ðə sɛl. "aɪ doʊn ɪɡzækli fil əlʊɹɪŋ ðiz deɪz."

"I've tried encouraging several of the serving men and Tower Guards," Leane said softly, sitting beside the bars of her cell. "But it's hard." She smiled, glancing at Egwene, who sat on a stool outside the cell. "I don't exactly feel alluring these days."

ɛɡwinz ɹɪspɑndɪŋ smaɪl wɑz ɹaɪ, ən ʃi sim tə ʌndɝstænd. lin wɔɹ ðə seɪm dʒɹɛs ðət ʃid bɪn kæptʃɝɾ ɪn, ən ɪt hæd nɑt jɛt bɪn lɔndɝd. ɛvɹi θɝd mɔɹnɪŋ, ʃi ɹimuvd ɪɾ ən juz ðə mɔɹnɪŋz bʌkəɾ ʌv wɔɾɝ - æftɝ wɑʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf klin wɪð ə dæmp ɹæɡ - tə klin ðə dʒɹɛs ɪn əɹ beɪsən. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli soʊ mʌtʃ wʌn kəd də wɪθaʊt soʊp. ʃid bɹeɪɾɪd əɹ hɛɹ tə ɡɪv ɪɾ ə sɛmbləns ə nitnəs, bʌt kəd də nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ ɹæɡəd neɪlz.

Egwene's responding smile was wry, and she seemed to understand. Leane wore the same dress that she'd been captured in, and it had not yet been laundered. Every third morning, she removed it and used the morning's bucket of water - after washing herself clean with a damp rag - to clean the dress in her basin. But there was only so much one could do without soap. She'd braided her hair to give it a semblance of neatness, but could do nothing about her ragged nails.

lin saɪd, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðoʊz mɔɹnɪŋz spɛn stændɪŋ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ sɛl, hɪɾən fɹəm saɪt, wɛɹɪŋ nʌθɪŋ waɪl ʃi weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə dʒɹɛs ən ʃɪf tə dʒɹaɪ. dʒʌs kəz ʃi wɑz dəmɑni dɪdn min ʃi laɪk pɝeɪɾɪŋ əbaʊt wɪθaʊɾ ə skɹæp ɑn. pɹɑpɝ sɪdʌkʃən ɹikwaɪɝd skɪl ən sʌɾəlti;

Leane sighed, thinking of those mornings spent standing in the corner of her cell, hidden from sight, wearing nothing while she waited for the dress and shift to dry. Just because she was Domani didn't mean she liked parading about without a scrap on. Proper seduction required skill and subtlety;

nuɾɪti juz niðɝ.

nudity used neither.

hɝ sɛl wɑzn bæɾ əz sɛlz wɛnt - ʃi hæɾ ə smɔl bɛd, milz, plɛnti ʌv wɔɾɝ, ə tʃeɪmbɝ pɑt ðət wɑz tʃeɪnʒd deɪli. bʌt ʃi wɑz nɛvɝ əlaʊɾ aʊt, ən wɑz ɔlweɪz ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ tu sɪstɝz u kɛpt əɹ ʃildɪd. ði oʊnli wʌn u vɪzəɾəd əɹ - seɪv fəɹ ðoʊz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹaɪ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fɹəm əɹ ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ tʃɹævlɪŋ - wɑz ɛɡwin.

Her cell wasn't bad as cells went - she had a small bed, meals, plenty of water, a chamber pot that was changed daily. But she was never allowed out, and was always guarded by two sisters who kept her shielded. The only one who visited her - save for those trying to pry information from her regarding Traveling - was Egwene.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sæɾ ɑn əɹ stul, ɪkspɹɛʃən θɔtfəl. ən ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə θɪŋk ə hɝ ɛni ʌðɝ weɪ. haʊ kəɾ ə tʃaɪl soʊ jʌŋ əv lɝn soʊ kwɪkli? ðət stʃɹeɪt bæk, ðət pɔɪzd ɪkspɹɛʃən. biɪŋ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl wɑzn soʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðə paʊɝ jə hæd, bʌt ðə paʊɝ jə ɪmplaɪd ðət jə hæd. ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ laɪk dilɪŋ wɪð mɛn, æktʃəli .

The Amyrlin sat on her stool, expression thoughtful. And she was Amyrlin. It was impossible to think of her any other way. How could a child so young have learned so quickly? That straight back, that poised expression. Being in control wasn't so much about the power you had, but the power you implied that you had. It was much like dealing with men, actually.

"hæv jə . . . hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ?" lin æskt. "əbaʊt wʌt ðeɪ plæn tə də wɪð mi?"

"Have you . . . heard anything?" Leane asked. "About what they plan to do with me?"

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. tu jɛloʊ sɪstɝz sæt tʃæɾɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ ɑn ðə bɛntʃ, lɪt baɪ ə læmp ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪsaɪd ðɛm. lin hædn ænsɝɾ ɛni ʌv ðə kwɛstʃənz əɹ kæptɝz pʊt tə hɝ, ən taʊɝ lɔ wɑz vɛɹi stʃɹɪkt əbaʊt ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ ə fɛloʊ sɪstɝz. ðeɪ kʊdn hɑɹm hɝ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli nɑt wɪð ðə paʊɝ. bʌt ðeɪ kəd dʒʌs liv əɹ əloʊn, tə ɹɑt.

Egwene shook her head. Two Yellow sisters sat chatting nearby on the bench, lit by a lamp on the table beside them. Leane hadn't answered any of the questions her captors put to her, and Tower law was very strict about the questioning of fellow sisters. They couldn't harm her, particularly not with the Power. But they could just leave her alone, to rot.

"θæŋk jə fəɹ kʌmɪŋ tə si mi ðiz ivnɪŋz," lin sɛd, ɹitʃɪŋ θɹu ðə læɾəs ə bɑɹz tə teɪk ɛɡwinz hænd. "aɪ bɪliv aɪ oʊ maɪ sænəɾi tə ju."

"Thank you for coming to see me these evenings," Leane said, reaching through the lattice of bars to take Egwene's hand. "I believe I owe my sanity to you."

"ɪɾ ɪz maɪ plɛʒɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd, ðoʊ hɝ aɪz ʃoʊɾ ə hɪn ə ði ɪɡzɔstʃən ʃi əndaʊɾɪdli fɛlt. səm ə ðə sɪstɝz u vɪzəɾəd lin mɛnʃən ðə biɾɪŋz ɛɡwin wɑz sʌfɝɪŋ əz "pɛnənsɪz" fəɹ əɹ ɪnsəbɔɹɾəneɪʃən. ɑd, haʊ ə nɑvəs tə bi ɪnstʃɹʌktəd kəd bi biɾən bʌɾ ə pɹɪznɝ tə bi ɪntɛɹəɡeɪɾɪd kəd nɑt. ən dɪspaɪt ðə peɪn, ɛɡwin keɪm tə vɪzət lin ɪn ðə sɛl vɝtʃuəli ɛvɹi naɪt.

"It is my pleasure," Egwene said, though her eyes showed a hint of the exhaustion she undoubtedly felt. Some of the sisters who visited Leane mentioned the beatings Egwene was suffering as "penances" for her insubordination. Odd, how a novice to be instructed could be beaten but a prisoner to be interrogated could not. And despite the pain, Egwene came to visit Leane in the cell virtually every night.

"aɪ wɪl si jə fɹi, lin," ɛɡwin pɹɑməst, stɪl hoʊldɪŋ əɹ hænd. "ɪleɪɾəz tɪɹəni kænɑt læst. aɪm kɑnfəɾənt ɪt woʊn bi lɔŋ naʊ."

"I will see you free, Leane," Egwene promised, still holding her hand. "Elaida's tyranny cannot last. I'm confident it won't be long now."

lin nɑɾəd, lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ ən stændɪŋ ʌp. ɛɡwin tʊk hoʊld ə ðə bɑɹz ən pʊl hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fit, kɹɪŋɪŋ ɛvɝ soʊ slaɪtli ət ðə moʊʃən. ʃi nɑɾəd fɛɹwɛl tə lin, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

Leane nodded, letting go and standing up. Egwene took hold of the bars and pulled herself to her feet, cringing ever so slightly at the motion. She nodded farewell to Leane, then hesitated, frowning.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" lin æskt.

"What is it?" Leane asked.

ɛɡwin tʊk əɹ hænz ɔf ə ðə bɑɹz ən lʊkt əɾ əɹ pɑmz. ðeɪ sim tə bi koʊɾəd wɪð ə ɹɪflɛktɪv, wæksi sʌbstəns. fɹaʊnɪŋ, lin lʊkt ət ðə bɑɹz, ən wɑz ʃɑk tə si ɛɡwinz hændpɹɪns ɑn ði aɪɝn.

Egwene took her hands off of the bars and looked at her palms. They seemed to be coated with a reflective, waxy substance. Frowning, Leane looked at the bars, and was shocked to see Egwene's handprints on the iron.

"wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt - " lin sɛd, poʊkɪŋ ət wʌn ə ðə bɑɹz. ɪt bɛn bɪniθ əɹ fɪŋɡɝ laɪk wɔɹm wæks ɑn ðə lɪp ʌv ə kændəlz boʊl.

"What in the Light - " Leane said, poking at one of the bars. It bent beneath her finger like warm wax on the lip of a candle's bowl.

sʌɾənli, ðə stoʊnz bɪniθ linz fit ʃɪftəd, ən ʃi fɛl hɝsɛlf sɪŋkɪŋ. ʃi kɹaɪɾ aʊt.

Suddenly, the stones beneath Leane's feet shifted, and she felt herself sinking. She cried out.

ɡlɑbz ə mɛltəd wæks stɑɹɾɪŋ tə ɹeɪn daʊn fɹəm ðə silɪŋ, splɑɾɝɪŋ əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs. ðeɪ wɝnt wɔɹm, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ sʌmhaʊ lɪkwəd. ðeɪ hæd ðə kʌlɝ ə stoʊn!

Globs of melted wax starting to rain down from the ceiling, splattering across her face. They weren't warm, but they were somehow liquid. They had the color of stone!

ʃi ɡæspt, pænɪkt, stʌmbəlɪŋ ən slaɪɾɪŋ əz əɹ fit sæŋk dipɝ ɪn ðə tu-slɪk flɔɹ. ə hæn kɑt hɝz; ʃi lʊkt ʌp tə wɛɹ ɛɡwin hæd ɡɹæb hɝ. ðə bɑɹz mɛltəɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ əz lin wɑtʃt, ði aɪɝn dʒɹupɪŋ tə ðə saɪdz, ðən lɪkəfaɪɪŋ.

She gasped, panicked, stumbling and sliding as her feet sank deeper in the too-slick floor. A hand caught hers; she looked up to where Egwene had grabbed her. The bars melted out of the way as Leane watched, the iron drooping to the sides, then liquefying.

"hɛlp!" ɛɡwin skɹimd ət ðə jɛloʊz aʊtsaɪd. "bɝn ju! stɑp stɛɹɪŋ!"

"Help!" Egwene screamed at the Yellows outside. "Burn you! Stop staring!"

lin skɹæmbəl fəɹ pɝtʃəs, tɛɹəfaɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl hɝsɛlf əlɔŋ ðə bɑɹz təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwin. ʃi ɡɹæspt oʊnli wæks. ə lʌmp ə bɑɹ keɪm lus ɪn əɹ hænd, skwɪʃɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ən ðə flɔɹ wɔɹpt ɝaʊn hɝ, sʌkɪŋ əɹ daʊn.

Leane scrambled for purchase, terrified, trying to pull herself along the bars toward Egwene. She grasped only wax. A lump of bar came loose in her hand, squishing between her fingers, and the floor warped around her, sucking her down.

ən ðən θɹɛdz ʌv ɛɹ siz hɝ, jæŋkɪŋ əɹ fɹi. ðə ɹum lɝtʃt əz ʃi wɑz tɔs fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə ɛɡwin, nɑkɪŋ ðə jʌŋɡɝ wʊmən bækwɝd. ðə tu jɛloʊz - waɪt-hɛɹd musɝɪn ən ʃɔɹt dʒɛlɑɹnə - hæd dʒʌmp tə ðɛɹ fit, ən ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd ðɛm. musɝɪn kɔl fəɹ hɛlp, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mɛltɪŋ sɛl wɪð waɪɾ aɪz.

And then threads of Air seized her, yanking her free. The room lurched as she was tossed forward into Egwene, knocking the younger woman backward. The two Yellows - white-haired Musarin and short Gelarna - had jumped to their feet, and the glow of saidar surrounded them. Musarin called for help, watching the melting cell with wide eyes.

lin ɹaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf, skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɔf ʌv ɛɡwin, hɝ dʒɹɛs ən lɛɡz koʊɾəd wɪð ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ wæks, ən stʌmbəl bæk əweɪ fɹəm ðə sɛl. ðə flɔɹ hɪɹ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ fɛl steɪbəl. laɪt, haʊ ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəɾ ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs hɝsɛlf! bʌt ʃi wɑz tu fʊl ə fɔkɹut, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə ʃild.

Leane righted herself, scrambling off of Egwene, her dress and legs coated with the strange wax, and stumbled back away from the cell. The floor here in the hallway felt stable. Light, how she wished she could embrace the source herself! But she was too full of forkroot, not to mention the shield.

ɛɡwin klaɪm tə hɝ fit wɪð ə hæn fɹəm lin. ðə ɹum fɛl stɪl, læmp flɪkɝɪŋ, ɔl ə ðɛm stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə sɛl. ðə mɛltɪŋ hæd stɑpt, ðə bɑɹz splɪt, ðə tɑp hævz fɹoʊzən wɪð dʒɹɪps ə stil ɑn ðɛɹ tɪps, ðə loʊɝ hævz bɛn ɪnwɝd. mɛni hæd bɪn flæɾənd tə ðə stoʊnz baɪ linz ɪskeɪp. ðə flɔɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum hæd baʊɾ ɪnwɝd, laɪk ə fʌnəl, ðə ɹɑks stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ. ðoʊz stoʊnz bɔɹ ɡæʃəz wɛɹ linz skɹæmbəlɪŋ hæd skɔɹd ðɛm.

Egwene climbed to her feet with a hand from Leane. The room fell still, lamp flickering, all of them staring at the cell. The melting had stopped, the bars split, the top halves frozen with drips of steel on their tips, the lower halves bent inward. Many had been flattened to the stones by Leane's escape. The floor inside the room had bowed inward, like a funnel, the rocks stretching. Those stones bore gashes where Leane's scrambling had scored them.

lin stʊd, hɝ hɑɹt biɾɪŋ, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ oʊnli sɛkənz hæd pæst. wʌt ʃəd ðeɪ du?

Leane stood, her heart beating, realizing that only seconds had passed. What should they do?

skʌɾəl əweɪ ɪn fɪɹ? wɑz ðə ɹɛst ə ðə hɔlweɪ ɡoʊɪŋ tə mɛlt, tu?

Scuttle away in fear? Was the rest of the hallway going to melt, too?

ɛɡwin stɛp fɔɹwɝd, tæpɪŋ əɹ toʊ əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə bɑɹz. ɪt ɹɪzɪstɪd. lin tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ən əɹ dʒɹɛs kɹʌntʃt, bɪts ə stoʊn - laɪk mɔɹɾɝ - fɔlɪŋ fɹi. ʃi ɹitʃt daʊn ən bɹʌʃt əɾ əɹ skɝt, ən fɛlt ɹʌf ɹɑk koʊɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wæks.

Egwene stepped forward, tapping her toe against one of the bars. It resisted. Leane took a step forward, and her dress crunched, bits of stone - like mortar - falling free. She reached down and brushed at her skirt, and felt rough rock coating it instead of wax.

"ðiz sɔɹts ʌv ɪvɛns ɑɹ mɔɹ fɹikwənt," ɛɡwin sɛd kɑmli, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə tu jɛloʊz.

"These sorts of events are more frequent," Egwene said calmly, glancing at the two Yellows.

"ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ stʃɹɔŋɝ. ðə læs bæɾəl əpɹoʊtʃɪz. wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ æmɪɝlɪn duɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt?"

"The Dark One is getting stronger. The Last Battle approaches. What is your Amyrlin doing about it?"

musɝɪn ɡlænst ət hɝ; ðə tɔl, eɪdʒɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊk dipli dɪstɝbd. lin tʊk ɛɡwinz lɛd, fɔɹsɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə bi kɑm əz ʃi stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd ði æmɪɝlɪn, tʃɪps ə stoʊn fɔlɪŋ fɹəm əɹ dʒɹɛs.

Musarin glanced at her; the tall, aging Aes Sedai looked deeply disturbed. Leane took Egwene's lead, forcing herself to be calm as she stepped up beside the Amyrlin, chips of stone falling from her dress.

"jɛs, wɛl," musɝɪn sɛd. "ju ʃæl ɹɪtɝn tə jəɹ ɹumz, nɑvəs. ən jə . . ." ʃi ɡlænst ət lin, ðən ət ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə sɛl. "wi wɪl . . . hæv tə ɹiloʊkeɪt ju."

"Yes, well," Musarin said. "You shall return to your rooms, novice. And you . . ." She glanced at Leane, then at the remains of the cell. "We will . . . have to relocate you."

"ænd ɡɛt mi ə nu dʒɹɛs əz wɛl, aɪ əsum," lin sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz.

"And get me a new dress as well, I assume," Leane said, folding her arms.

musɝɪnz aɪz flɪkɝɾ əɾ ɛɡwin. "ɡoʊ. ðɪs ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ jəɹ bɪznəs, tʃaɪld. wɪl kɛɹ fəɹ ðə pɹɪznɝ."

Musarin's eyes flickered at Egwene. "Go. This is no longer your business, child. We will care for the prisoner."

ɛɡwin ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ, bʌt ðən ʃi tɝn tə lin. "steɪ stʃɹɔŋ," ʃi sɛd, ən hɝiɾ əweɪ, hɛɾɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ.

Egwene gritted her teeth, but then she turned to Leane. "Stay strong," she said, and hurried away, heading down the hallway.

ɪɡzɔstəd, dɪstɝbd baɪ ðə stoʊn-wɔɹpɪŋ bʌbəl ʌv ivəl, ɛɡwin wɔkt wɪð swɪʃɪŋ skɝts təwɔɹd ðə taʊɝ wɪŋ ðət kənteɪn ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz. wʌt wəɾ ɪt teɪk tə kənvɪns ðə fulɪʃ wɪmən ðət ðəɹ wɑzn taɪm tə spɛɹ fəɹ skwɑbəlɪŋ!

Exhausted, disturbed by the stone-warping bubble of evil, Egwene walked with swishing skirts toward the Tower wing that contained the novices' quarters. What would it take to convince the foolish women that there wasn't time to spare for squabbling!

ði aʊɝ wɑz leɪt, ən fju wɪmən wɔk ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz, nʌn ə ðɛm nɑvəsɪz. ɛɡwin pæst sɛvɹəl sɝvəns bʌsəlɪŋ ət leɪt-naɪt duɾiz, ðɛɹ slɪpɝd fit fɔlɪŋ sɔfli ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. ðiz sɛktɝz ə ðə taʊɝ wɝ pɑpjəleɪɾəd ɪnʌf ðət læmps bɝn ɑn ðə wɔlz, tʃɹɪm loʊ, ɡɪvɪŋ ən ɔɹənʒ laɪt. ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɹən pɑlɪʃt taɪlz ɹəflɛktəd ðə flɪkɝɪŋ fleɪmz, lʊkɪŋ laɪk aɪz ðət wɑtʃt ɛɡwin əz ʃi wɔkt.

The hour was late, and few women walked the corridors, none of them novices. Egwene passed several servants bustling at late-night duties, their slippered feet falling softly on the floor tiles. These sectors of the Tower were populated enough that lamps burned on the walls, trimmed low, giving an orange light. A hundred different polished tiles reflected the flickering flames, looking like eyes that watched Egwene as she walked.

ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə kɑmpɹihɛn ðət ðɪs kwaɪəɾ ivnɪŋ hæd tɝn ɪndə ə tʃɹæp ðət nɪɹli kɪld lin. ɪf ivən ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪtsɛlf kəd nɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪd, ðən wʌt kʊd? ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, tu taɪɝd, tu sɔɹ, tə θɪŋk ə səluʃənz ət ðə moʊmənt. ʃi bɛɹli noʊɾəst wən ðə flɔɹ taɪlz tɝn fɹəm ɡɹeɪ tə ə dip bɹaʊn. ʃi dʒʌs kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn, ɪndə ðə taʊɝ wɪŋ, kaʊntɪŋ ðə dɔɹz ʃi pæst. hɝz wɑz ðə sɛvənθ . . .

It was hard to comprehend that this quiet evening had turned into a trap that nearly killed Leane. If even the ground itself could not be trusted, then what could? Egwene shook her head, too tired, too sore, to think of solutions at the moment. She barely noticed when the floor tiles turned from gray to a deep brown. She just continued on, into the Tower wing, counting the doors she passed. Hers was the seventh . . .

ʃi fɹoʊz, fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ə pɛɹ ə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz: mɑɛnædʒɹɪn - ə sɑldəiən - ən nəɡeɪn. ðə tu hæd bɪn spikɪŋ ɪn hʌʃt wɪspɝz, ən ðeɪ fɹaʊn əɾ ɛɡwin əz ʃi pæs ðɛm. waɪ wəd ðeɪ bi ɪn ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz?

She froze, frowning at a pair of Brown sisters: Maenadrin - a Saldaean - and Negaine. The two had been speaking in hushed whispers, and they frowned at Egwene as she passed them. Why would they be in the novices' quarters?

bʌt weɪt. ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz dɪdn əv bɹaʊn flɔɹ taɪlz. ðɪs sɛkʃən ʃʊɾə hæd nɑndɪskɹɪpt ɡɹeɪ taɪlz. ən ðə dɔɹz ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ wɝ speɪs fɑɹ tu waɪdli. ðɪs dɪdn lʊk əɾ ɔl laɪk ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz! hæd ʃi bɪn soʊ taɪɝd ðət ʃid wɔkt ɪn kəmplitli ðə ɹɔŋ dɝɛkʃən?

But wait. The novices' quarters didn't have brown floor tiles. This section should have had nondescript gray tiles. And the doors in the hallway were spaced far too widely. This didn't look at all like the novices' quarters! Had she been so tired that she'd walked in completely the wrong direction?

ʃi ɹitʃɹeɪst əɹ stɛps, pæsɪŋ ðə tu bɹaʊn sɪstɝz əɡɛn. ʃi faʊn ə wɪndoʊ ən lʊkt aʊt.

She retraced her steps, passing the two Brown sisters again. She found a window and looked out.

ðə ɹɛktæŋɡjəlɝ waɪɾ ɪkspæns ə ðə taʊɝ wɪŋ ɪkstɛndəɾ ɝaʊn hɝ, dʒʌst əz ɪt ʃʊd. ʃi wɑzn lɔst.

The rectangular white expanse of the Tower wing extended around her, just as it should. She wasn't lost.

pɝplɛkst, ʃi lʊk bæk daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. mɑɛnædʒɹɪn hæd foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɛɡwin wɪð ə sɛɾ ə dɑɹk aɪz. nəɡeɪn, tɔl ən spɪnli, stɔkt ʌp tə ɛɡwin. "wʌt bɪznəs əv jə hɪɹ ðɪs taɪm ə naɪt, tʃaɪld?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "dɪɾ ə sɪstɝ sɛn fəɹ ju? jə ʃəd bi bæk ɪn jəɹ ɹum fəɹ slip."

Perplexed, she looked back down the hallway. Maenadrin had folded her arms, regarding Egwene with a set of dark eyes. Negaine, tall and spindly, stalked up to Egwene. "What business have you here this time of night, child?" she demanded. "Did a sister send for you? You should be back in your room for sleep."

wɝdləsli, ɛɡwin pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ. nəɡeɪn ɡlænst aʊt, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ʃi fɹoʊz, ɡæspɪŋ sɔfli. ʃi lʊk bæk ɪn ət ðə hɔlweɪ, ðən bæk aʊt, əz ɪf əneɪbəl tə bɪliv wɛɹ ʃi wɑz.

Wordlessly, Egwene pointed out the window. Negaine glanced out, frowning. She froze, gasping softly. She looked back in at the hallway, then back out, as if unable to believe where she was.

ɪn mɪnəts, ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ wɑz ɪn ə fɹɛnzi. ɛɡwin, fɝɡɑɾən, stʊɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə hɔlweɪ wɪð ə klʌstɝ ə blɪɹi-aɪd nɑvəsɪz əz sɪstɝz ɑɹɡjud wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn tɛns vɔɪsəz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dətɝmən wʌt tə du. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət tu sɛkʃənz ə ðə taʊɝ hæd bɪn swɑpt, ən ðə slʌmbɝɪŋ bɹaʊn sɪstɝz hæd bɪn muv fɹəm ðɛɹ sɛkʃənz ɑn ði ʌpɝ lɛvəlz daʊn ɪndə ðə wɪŋ.

In minutes, the entire Tower was in a frenzy. Egwene, forgotten, stood at the side of a hallway with a cluster of bleary-eyed novices as sisters argued with one another in tense voices, trying to determine what to do. It appeared that two sections of the Tower had been swapped, and the slumbering Brown sisters had been moved from their sections on the upper levels down into the wing.

ðə nɑvəsɪz' ɹumz - ɪntækt - hæd bɪn pleɪst wɛɹ ðə sɛkʃən ə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz hæd bɪn. noʊbɑdi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɛni moʊʃən əɹ vaɪbɹeɪʃən wən ðə swɑp hæpənd, ən ðə tʃɹænsfɝ əpɪɹd simləs. ə laɪn ə flɔɹ taɪlz hæd bɪn splɪt ɹaɪt daʊn ðə mɪɾəl, ðən mɛldəd wɪð taɪlz fɹəm ðə sɛkʃən ðət hæd ʃɪftəd.

The novices' rooms - intact - had been placed where the section of Brown sisters had been. Nobody remembered any motion or vibration when the swap happened, and the transfer appeared seamless. A line of floor tiles had been split right down the middle, then melded with tiles from the section that had shifted.

ɪts ɡɛɾɪŋ wɝs ən wɝs, ɛɡwin θɔɾ əz ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz dɪsaɪɾɪd - fəɹ naʊ - ðət ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə æksɛp ðə swɪtʃ. ðeɪ kʊdn vɛɹi wɛl muv sɪstɝz ɪndə ɹumz ðə saɪz ðət nɑvəsɪz juzd.

It's getting worse and worse, Egwene thought as the Brown sisters decided - for now - that they would have to accept the switch. They couldn't very well move sisters into rooms the size that novices used.

ðət wəd liv ðə bɹaʊnz dɪvaɪɾəd, hæf ɪn ðə wɪŋ, hæf ɪn ðɛɹ oʊld loʊkeɪʃən - wɪð ə klʌmp ə nɑvəsɪz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðɛm. ə dɪvɪʒən æpli ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪv ə ðə lɛs-vɪzəbəl dɪvɪʒənz ði ədʒəz wɝ sʌfɝɪŋ.

That would leave the Browns divided, half in the wing, half in their old location - with a clump of novices in the middle of them. A division aptly representative of the less-visible divisions the Ajahs were suffering.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɪɡzɔstəd, ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ sɛn ɔf tə slip - ðoʊ naʊ ʃi hæd tə tʃɹʌdʒ ʌp mɛni flaɪts ə stɛɹz bɪfɔɹ ɹitʃɪŋ əɹ bɛd.

Eventually, exhausted, Egwene and the others were sent off to sleep - though now she had to trudge up many flights of stairs before reaching her bed.

tʃæptɝ sɛvən

CHAPTER 7

ðə plæn fəɹ ɑɹæd dumən "ə stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, lʊkɪŋ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ ʌv ðə mænɝ.

The Plan for Arad Doman "A storm is coming," Nynaeve said, looking out the window of the manor.

"jɛs," ɹɪplaɪd deɪdʒiən fɹəm əɹ tʃɛɹ baɪ ðə hɑɹθ wɪθaʊt bɑðɝɪŋ tə ɡlæns ət ðə wɪndoʊ. "aɪ θɪŋk jə maɪt bi ɹaɪt, dɪɹ. aɪ swɛɹ, ɪt simz əz ɪf ɪts bɪn oʊvɝkæs fəɹ wiks!"

"Yes," replied Daigian from her chair by the hearth without bothering to glance at the window. "I think you might be right, dear. I swear, it seems as if it has been overcast for weeks!"

"ɪɾ əz bɪn ə sɪŋɡəl wik," nɪneɪiv sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ lɔŋ, dɑɹk bɹeɪɾ ɪn wʌn hænd. ʃi ɡlænst ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. "aɪ hævən sin ə pætʃ ə klɪɹ skaɪ ɪn oʊvɝ tɛn deɪz."

"It has been a single week," Nynaeve said, holding her long, dark braid in one hand. She glanced at the other woman. "I haven't seen a patch of clear sky in over ten days."

deɪdʒiən fɹaʊnd. ʌv ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ, ʃi wɑz plʌmp ən kɝveɪsəs. ʃi wɔɹ ə smɔl stoʊn ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛɾ əz mɔɪɹeɪn hæd soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, ðoʊ deɪdʒiənz wɑz ən əpɹoʊpɹiɪtli waɪt munstoʊn.

Daigian frowned. Of the White Ajah, she was plump and curvaceous. She wore a small stone on her forehead as Moiraine had so long ago, though Daigian's was an appropriately white moonstone.

ðə tʃɹədɪʃən əpɛɹənli hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð biɪŋ ə kɛɹhin noʊbəlwʊmən, əz dɪd ðə fɔɹ kʌlɝd slæʃɪz ðə wʊmən wɔɹ ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs.

The tradition apparently had something to do with being a Cairhien noblewoman, as did the four colored slashes the woman wore on her dress.

"tɛn deɪz, jə seɪ?" deɪdʒiən sɛd. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən?"

"Ten days, you say?" Daigian said. "Are you certain?"

nɪneɪiv wɑz. ʃi peɪɾ ətɛnʃən tə ðə wɛðɝ; ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə duɾiz ʌv ə vɪlədʒ wɪzdəm.

Nynaeve was. She paid attention to the weather; that was one of the duties of a village Wisdom.

ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ naʊ, bʌt ðət dɪdn min ʃi stɑp biɪŋ u ʃi wɑz. ðə wɛðɝ wɑz ɔlweɪz ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ maɪnd. ʃi kəd sɛns ðə ɹeɪn, sʌn, əɹ snoʊ ɪn ðə wɪnz wɪspɝz.

She was Aes Sedai now, but that didn't mean she stopped being who she was. The weather was always there, in the back of her mind. She could sense the rain, sun, or snow in the wind's whispers.

leɪtli, haʊɛvɝ, ðə sɛnseɪʃənz hædn bɪn laɪk wɪspɝz əɾ ɔl. mɔɹ laɪk dɪstənt ʃaʊts, ɡɹoʊɪŋ laʊɾɝ. əɹ laɪk weɪvz kɹæʃɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ, stɪl fɑɹ tə ðə nɔɹθ, jɛt hɑɹɾɝ ən hɑɹɾɝ tə ɪɡnɔɹ.

Lately, however, the sensations hadn't been like whispers at all. More like distant shouts, growing louder. Or like waves crashing against one another, still far to the north, yet harder and harder to ignore.

"wɛl," deɪdʒiən sɛd, "aɪm sɝɾən ðɪs ɪzən ði oʊnli taɪm ɪn hɪstɝi ðəɾ ɪts bɪn klaʊɾi fəɹ tɛn deɪz!"

"Well," Daigian said, "I'm certain this isn't the only time in history that it has been cloudy for ten days!"

nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, tʌɡɪŋ ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd. "ɪts nɑt nɔɹməl," ʃi sɛd. "æn ðoʊz oʊvɝkæst skaɪz ɑɹən ðə stɔɹm aɪm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt. ɪts stɪl dɪstənt, bʌɾ ɪts kʌmɪŋ. ən ɪts gɑnə bi tɛɹəbəl.

Nynaeve shook her head, tugging on her braid. "It's not normal," she said. "And those overcast skies aren't the storm I'm talking about. It's still distant, but it's coming. And it is going to be terrible.

wɝs ðən ɛni aɪv ɛvɝ sin. fɑɹ wɝs."

Worse than any I've ever seen. Far worse."

"wɛl, ðɛn," deɪdʒiən sɛd, saʊndɪŋ slaɪtli ənkʌmftəɹbəl, "wi wɪl dil wɪð ɪt wən ɪɾ ɝaɪvz. ɑɹ jə gɑnə sɪt daʊn soʊ ðət wi kən kəntɪnju?"

"Well, then," Daigian said, sounding slightly uncomfortable, "we will deal with it when it arrives. Are you going to sit down so that we can continue?"

nɪneɪiv ɡlænst ət ðə plʌmp ɛɛs sədaɪ. deɪdʒiən wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli wik ɪn ðə paʊɝ. ðə waɪt maɪt dʒʌs bi ðə wikəst ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət nɪneɪiv hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛt. baɪ tʃɹədɪʃənəl - jɛɾ ənspoʊkən - ɹulz, ðət mɛn ðət nɪneɪiv ʃəd bi əlaʊd tə teɪk ðə lɛd.

Nynaeve glanced at the plump Aes Sedai. Daigian was extremely weak in the Power. The White might just be the weakest Aes Sedai that Nynaeve had ever met. By traditional - yet unspoken - rules, that meant that Nynaeve should be allowed to take the lead.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, nɪneɪivz pəzɪʃən wɑz stɪl kwɛstʃənəbəl. ɛɡwin hæd ɹeɪzd əɹ tə ðə ʃɔl baɪ dɪkɹi, dʒʌst əz ʃid ɹeɪzd ɪleɪn: ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ tɛstɪŋ, nɔɹ hæd nɪneɪiv swɔɹn ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd. tə moʊst - ivən ðoʊz u æksɛptɪɾ ɛɡwinz pleɪs əz ðə tʃɹu æmɪɝlɪn - ðoʊz oʊmɪʃənz meɪd nɪneɪiv sʌmθɪŋ lɛs ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɑɾ ən æksɛptɪd, bʌt hɑɹdli ikwəl tə ə sɪstɝ.

Unfortunately, Nynaeve's position was still questionable. Egwene had raised her to the shawl by decree, just as she'd raised Elayne: there had been no testing, nor had Nynaeve sworn on the Oath Rod. To most - even those who accepted Egwene's place as the true Amyrlin - those omissions made Nynaeve something less than Aes Sedai. Not an Accepted, but hardly equal to a sister.

ðə sɪstɝz wɪð kædzueɪn wɝ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli bæd, əz ðeɪ hædn dɪklɛɹd fəɹ iðɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝ əɹ ðə ɹɛbəlz. ən ðə sɪstɝz swɔɹn tə ɹænd wɝ wɝs; moʊst wɝ stɪl lɔɪəl tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, nɑt siɪŋ ə pɹɑbləm wɪð səpɔɹɾɪŋ boʊθ ɪleɪɾə ən ɹænd. nɪneɪiv stɪl wʌndɝd wʌt ɹænd hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ, əlaʊɪŋ sɪstɝz tə swɛɹ fiəlti tə hɪm. ʃiɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪz mɪsteɪk tə hɪm ɑn sɛvɹəl əkeɪʒənz - kwaɪt ɹæʃənəli - bʌt tɔkɪŋ tə ɹænd ðiz deɪz wɑz laɪk tɔkɪŋ tə ə stoʊn.

The sisters with Cadsuane were particularly bad, as they hadn't declared for either the White Tower or the rebels. And the sisters sworn to Rand were worse; most were still loyal to the White Tower, not seeing a problem with supporting both Elaida and Rand. Nynaeve still wondered what Rand had been thinking, allowing sisters to swear fealty to him. She'd explained his mistake to him on several occasions - quite rationally - but talking to Rand these days was like talking to a stone.

oʊnli lɛs ɪfɛktɪv ən ɪnfənətli mɔɹ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ.

Only less effective and infinitely more infuriating.

deɪdʒiən wɑz stɪl weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə sɪt. ɹæðɝ ðən pɹəvoʊk ə kɑntɛst ʌv wɪlz, nɪneɪiv dɪd soʊ.

Daigian was still waiting for her to sit. Rather than provoke a contest of wills, Nynaeve did so.

deɪdʒiən wɑz stɪl sʌfɝɪŋ fɹəm hævɪŋ lɔst əɹ wɔɹɾɝ - ɛbən, ən æʃəmən - dʊɹɪŋ ðə faɪt wɪð ðə fɔɹseɪkən. nɪneɪiv hæd spɛn ðət faɪt kəmplitli əbzɔɹbd baɪ pɹəvaɪɾɪŋ ɹænd wɪð ɪmɛns əmaʊns ə seɪaɪdɑɹ tə wiv.

Daigian was still suffering from having lost her Warder - Eben, an Asha'man - during the fight with the Forsaken. Nynaeve had spent that fight completely absorbed by providing Rand with immense amounts of saidar to weave.

nɪneɪiv kəd stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə ʃɪɹ dʒɔɪ - ði ɑsəm jufɔɹiə, stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən ʃɪɹ fil ə laɪf - ðət hæd kʌm fɹəm dʒɹɔɪŋ ðət mʌtʃ paʊɝ. ɪt fɹaɪɾənd hɝ. ʃi wɑz ɡlæd ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ʃid juz tə tʌtʃ ðət paʊɝ hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd.

Nynaeve could still remember the sheer joy - the awesome euphoria, strength, and sheer feel of life - that had come from drawing that much power. It frightened her. She was glad the ter'angreal she'd used to touch that power had been destroyed.

bʌt ðə meɪl tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz stɪl ɪntækt: ən æksɛs ki tə ə paʊɝfəl sɑŋɡɹil. əz fɑɹ əz nɪneɪiv nu, ɹænd hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə pɝsweɪd kædzueɪn tə ɹɪtɝn ɪt tə hɪm. əz wɛl ʃi ʃʊdnt. noʊ hjumən biɪŋ, nɑɾ ivən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ʃəd tʃænəl ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

But the male ter'angreal was still intact: an access key to a powerful sa'angreal. As far as Nynaeve knew, Rand had not been able to persuade Cadsuane to return it to him. As well she shouldn't. No human being, not even the Dragon Reborn, should channel that much of the One Power.

ðə θɪŋz wʌn kəd bi tɛmptəd tə du. . . .

The things one could be tempted to do. . . .

ʃid toʊld ɹænd ðəɾ i niɾəd tə fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ði æksɛs ki. laɪk tɔkɪŋ tə ə stoʊn. ə bɪɡ, ɹɛd- hɛɹd, aɪɝn-feɪst ɪɾiət ʌv ə stoʊn. nɪneɪiv hæɹəmf tə hɝsɛlf. ðət kɑz deɪdʒiən tə ɹeɪz ən aɪbɹaʊ. ðə wʊmən wɑz kwaɪt ɡʊɾ ət kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ əɹ ɡɹif, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv - huz ɹum ɪn ðə dəmɑni mænʃən wɑz bɪsaɪd deɪdʒiənz - hɝd ðə wʊmən kɹaɪɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf ət naɪt. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi tə luz wʌnz wɔɹɾɝ.

She'd told Rand that he needed to forget about the access key. Like talking to a stone. A big, red- haired, iron-faced idiot of a stone. Nynaeve harrumphed to herself. That caused Daigian to raise an eyebrow. The woman was quite good at controlling her grief, though Nynaeve - whose room in the Domani mansion was beside Daigian's - heard the woman crying to herself at night. It was not easy to lose one's Warder.

læn. . . .

Lan. . . .

noʊ, bɛs nɑt tə θɪŋk ə hɪm ət ðə moʊmənt. læn wəd bi faɪn. oʊnli ət ði ɛn ə hɪz dʒɝni ʌv θaʊzənz ə maɪlz wəɾ i bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ɪt wɑz ðəɹ i ɪntɛndəd tə θɹoʊ hɪmsɛlf ət ðə ʃædoʊ laɪk ə loʊn æɹoʊ lust əɾ ə bɹɪk wɔl . . .

No, best not to think of him at the moment. Lan would be fine. Only at the end of his journey of thousands of miles would he be in danger. It was there he intended to throw himself at the Shadow like a lone arrow loosed at a brick wall . . .

noʊ! ʃi θɔt tə hɝsɛlf. hɪl nɑt bi əloʊn. aɪ sɔ tə ðæt.

No! she thought to herself. He will not be alone. I saw to that.

"vɛɹi wɛl," nɪneɪiv sɛd, fɔɹsɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə foʊkəs, "lɛɾ əs kəntɪnju." ʃi ʃoʊd noʊ dɛfɝəns tə deɪdʒiən. ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ðɪs wʊmən ə feɪvɝ, dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ əɹ fɹəm əɹ ɡɹif. ðət wɑz haʊ kɔɹəl hæɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪt, ɛniweɪ. ɪt wɑznt, sɝɾənli, fəɹ nɪneɪivz bɛnəfɪt ðət ðeɪ mɛt. ʃi hæd nʌθɪŋ tə pɹuv. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ði ʌðɝz θɔɾ əɹ ɪmplaɪd.

"Very well," Nynaeve said, forcing herself to focus, "let us continue." She showed no deference to Daigian. She was doing this woman a favor, distracting her from her grief. That was how Corele had explained it, anyway. It wasn't, certainly, for Nynaeve's benefit that they met. She had nothing to prove. She was Aes Sedai, no matter what the others thought or implied.

ðɪs wɑz ɔl dʒʌst ə ɹuz tə hɛlp deɪdʒiən. ðət wɑz ɪt. nʌθɪŋ ɛls.

This was all just a ruse to help Daigian. That was it. Nothing else.

"hɪɹ ɪz ði eɪɾi-fɝst wiv," ðə waɪt sɛd. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ spɹæŋ ʌp ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ʃi tʃænəld, kɹæftɪŋ ə vɛɹi kɑmplɛks wiv ə faɪɝ, ɛɹ ən spɪɹət. kɑmplɛks, bʌt jusləs. ðə wiv kɹieɪɾəd θɹi bɝnɪŋ ɹɪŋz ə faɪɝ ɪn ði ɛɹ wɪtʃ ɡloʊd wɪð ənjuʒəwəl laɪt, bʌt wʌt wɑz ðə pɔɪn ə ðæt? nɪneɪiv ɔlɹɛɾi nu haʊ tə meɪk faɪɝbɔlz ən bɔlz ə laɪt; waɪ weɪs taɪm lɝnɪŋ wivz ðət ɹɪpiɾɪd wʌt ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi nu, oʊnli ɪn ə fɑɹ mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd weɪ? ən waɪ dɪɾ itʃ ɹɪŋ əv tə bi ə slaɪtli dɪfɹən kʌlɝ?

"Here is the eighty-first weave," the White said. The glow of saidar sprang up around her, and she channeled, crafting a very complex weave of Fire, Air and Spirit. Complex, but useless. The weave created three burning rings of fire in the air which glowed with unusual light, but what was the point of that? Nynaeve already knew how to make fireballs and balls of light; why waste time learning weaves that repeated what she already knew, only in a far more complicated way? And why did each ring have to be a slightly different color?

nɪneɪiv weɪvd ən ɪndɪfɹən hænd, ɹɪpiɾɪŋ ðə wiv ɪɡzækli. "ɑnəsli," ʃi sɛd, "ðæt wʌn simz ðə moʊs jusləs ə ðə bʌntʃ! wʌɾ ɪz ðə pɔɪn ʌv ɔl ə ðiz?"

Nynaeve waved an indifferent hand, repeating the weave exactly. "Honestly," she said, "that one seems the most useless of the bunch! What is the point of all of these?"

deɪdʒiən pɝst əɹ lɪps. ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, bʌt nɪneɪiv nu ðət deɪdʒiən θɔt ðət ðɪs ɔl ʃəd bi fɑɹ mɔɹ dɪfəkəl fəɹ nɪneɪiv ðən ɪt wɑz. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðə wʊmən spoʊk. "ju kænɑt bi toʊl mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðə tɛstɪŋ. ði oʊnli θɪŋ aɪ kən seɪ ɪz ðət jəl nid tə ɹɪpit ðiz wivz ɪɡzækli, ən də soʊ waɪl ʌndɝɡoʊɪŋ ɪkstʃɹim dɪstʃɹækʃən. wən ðə taɪm kʌmz, jəl ʌndɝstænd."

Daigian pursed her lips. She said nothing, but Nynaeve knew that Daigian thought that this all should be far more difficult for Nynaeve than it was. Eventually, the woman spoke. "You cannot be told much about the testing. The only thing I can say is that you will need to repeat these weaves exactly, and do so while undergoing extreme distraction. When the time comes, you will understand."

"aɪ daʊɾ ɪt," nɪneɪiv sɛd flætli, kɑpiɪŋ ðə wiv θɹi taɪmz oʊvɝ waɪl ʃi spoʊk. "bɪkɔz  - əz aɪ bɪliv aɪv toʊl jə ə dʌzən taɪmz ɔlɹɛɾi - aɪm nɑt gɑnə bi teɪkɪŋ ðə tɛst. aɪm ɔlɹɛɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"I doubt it," Nynaeve said flatly, copying the weave three times over while she spoke. "Because  - as I believe I've told you a dozen times already - I'm not going to be taking the test. I'm already Aes Sedai."

"ʌv kɔɹs jə ɑɹ, dɪɹ."

"Of course you are, dear."

nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ. ðɪs hæd bɪn ə bæɾ aɪdiə. wən ʃiɾ əpɹoʊtʃt kɔɹəl -  səpoʊzədli ə mɛmbɝ ə nɪneɪivz oʊn ədʒɑ - ðə wʊmən hæd ɹəfjuz tə æknɑlɪdʒ əɹ əz ən ikwəl. ʃid bɪn plɛzən əbaʊɾ ɪt, əz kɔɹəl ɔfən wɑz, bʌt ði ɪmpləkeɪʃən hæd bɪn klɪɹ. ʃiɾ ivən sim sɪmpəθɛɾɪk. sɪmpəθɛɾɪk! əz ɪf nɪneɪiv niɾəd əɹ pɪɾi. ʃi hæd sədʒɛstəd ðəɾ ɪf nɪneɪiv nu ðə hʌnʒɹəd wivz itʃ æksɛptɪd lɝn fəɹ ðə tɛs tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪt maɪt hɛlp wɪð əɹ kɹɛɾəbɪlɪti.

Nynaeve ground her teeth. This had been a bad idea. When she'd approached Corele -  supposedly a member of Nynaeve's own Ajah - the woman had refused to acknowledge her as an equal. She'd been pleasant about it, as Corele often was, but the implication had been clear. She'd even seemed sympathetic. Sympathetic! As if Nynaeve needed her pity. She had suggested that if Nynaeve knew the hundred weaves each Accepted learned for the test to become Aes Sedai, it might help with her credibility.

ðə pɹɑbləm wɑz, ðɪs pleɪs nɪneɪiv ɪn ə sɪtʃueɪʃən wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ɔl bʌt tʃɹiɾəd əz ə stuɾənt əɡɛn. ʃi dɪd si ðə jus ɪn noʊɪŋ ðə hʌnʒɹəd wivz - ʃid spɛn fɑɹ tu ʃɔɹɾ ə taɪm stʌɾiɪŋ ðɛm, ən vɝtʃuəli ɛvɹi sɪstɝ nu ɪt. haʊɛvɝ, baɪ æksɛptɪŋ ðə lɛsənz, ʃi hædn mɛn tə ɪmplaɪ ðət ʃi sɔ hɝsɛlf əz ə stuɾənt!

The problem was, this placed Nynaeve in a situation where she was all but treated as a student again. She did see the use in knowing the hundred weaves - she'd spent far too short a time studying them, and virtually every sister knew it. However, by accepting the lessons, she hadn't meant to imply that she saw herself as a student!

ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ əɹ bɹeɪd, bʌt stɑp hɝsɛlf. hɝ vɪzəbəl ɪkspɹɛʃənz ʌv ɪmoʊʃən wɝ ənʌðɝ fæktɝ ɪn haʊ ʃi wɑz tʃɹiɾəd baɪ ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪf oʊnli ʃi hæd ðəɾ eɪdʒləs feɪs! bɑ!

She reached for her braid, but stopped herself. Her visible expressions of emotion were another factor in how she was treated by the other Aes Sedai. If only she had that ageless face! Bah!

deɪdʒiənz nɛkst wiv meɪɾ ə pɑpɪŋ saʊn ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən wʌns əɡɛn ðə wiv ɪtsɛlf wɑz nidləsli kɑmplɛks. nɪneɪiv kɑpiɾ ɪt wɪð bɛɹli ə θɔt, kəmɪɾɪŋ ɪt tə mɛmɹi ət ðə seɪm taɪm.

Daigian's next weave made a popping sound in the air, and once again the weave itself was needlessly complex. Nynaeve copied it with barely a thought, committing it to memory at the same time.

deɪdʒiən stɛɹɾ ət ðə wiv fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ə dɪstən lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs.

Daigian stared at the weave for a moment, a distant look on her face.

"wʌt?" nɪneɪiv æsk tɛstəli.

"What?" Nynaeve asked testily.

"m? oʊ, nʌθɪŋ. aɪ dʒʌst . . . ðə læs taɪm aɪ meɪd ðət wiv, aɪ juzd ɪt tə stɑɹɾəl . . . aɪ . . . nɛvɝ maɪnd."

"Hmm? Oh, nothing. I just . . . the last time I made that weave, I used it to startle . . . I . . . never mind."

ɛbən. hɝ wɔɹɾɝ hæd bɪn jʌŋ, meɪbi fɪftin əɹ sɪkstin, ən ʃi hæd bɪn vɛɹi fɑn ə hɪm.

Eben. Her Warder had been young, maybe fifteen or sixteen, and she had been very fond of him.

ɛbən ən deɪdʒiən hæd pleɪd ɡeɪmz təɡɛðɝ laɪk ə bɔɪ ən ən ɛldɝ sɪstɝ ɹæðɝ ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝ.

Eben and Daigian had played games together like a boy and an elder sister rather than Aes Sedai and Warder.

ə juθ ʌv oʊnli sɪkstin, nɪneɪiv θɔt, dɛd. dɪd ɹænd əv tə ɹəkɹuɾ əm soʊ jʌŋ?

A youth of only sixteen, Nynaeve thought, dead. Did Rand have to recruit them so young?

deɪdʒiənz feɪs ɡɹu stɪf, kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ðən nɪneɪiv wʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə.

Daigian's face grew stiff, controlling her emotions far better than Nynaeve would have been able to.

laɪt sɛn ðəɾ aɪm nɛvɝ ɪn ðə seɪm sɪtʃueɪʃən, ʃi θɔt. ət lis nɑt fəɹ mɛni, mɛni jɪɹz.

Light send that I'm never in the same situation, she thought. At least not for many, many years.

læn wɑzn əɹ wɔɹɾɝ jɛt, bʌt ʃi mɛn tə hæv ɪm əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi hɝ hʌzbənd, æftɝ ɔl. ɪt stɪl æŋɡɝɾ əɹ ðət maɪɹɛl hæd ðə bɑnd.

Lan wasn't her Warder yet, but she meant to have him as soon as possible. He was already her husband, after all. It still angered her that Myrelle had the bond.

"aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə hɛlp, deɪdʒiən," nɪneɪiv sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, leɪɪŋ əɹ hæn ɑn ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ni. "ɪf aɪ wɝ tə ətɛmpt ə hilɪŋ, pɝhæps. . . ."

"I might be able to help, Daigian," Nynaeve said, leaning forward, laying her hand on the other woman's knee. "If I were to attempt a Healing, perhaps. . . ."

"noʊ," ðə wʊmən sɛd kɝtli.

"No," the woman said curtly.

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"aɪ daʊt jə kəd hɛlp."

"I doubt you could help."

"ɛniθɪŋ kən bi hild," nɪneɪiv sɛd stʌbɝnli, "ivən ɪf wi doʊnt noʊ haʊ jɛt. ɛniθɪŋ seɪv dɛθ."

"Anything can be Healed," Nynaeve said stubbornly, "even if we don't know how yet. Anything save death."

"ænd wʌt wəd jə du, dɪɹ?" deɪdʒiən æskt. nɪneɪiv wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi ɹəfjuz tə kɔl əɹ baɪ neɪm ɑn pɝpəs, əɹ ɪf ɪt wɑz ən ʌnkɑnʃəs ɪfɛkt ə ðɛɹ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp. ʃi kʊdn juz "tʃaɪld," əz ʃi wəd wɪð ən æktʃəwəl æksɛptɪd, bʌt tə kɔl əɹ "nɪneɪiv" maɪɾ ɪmplaɪ ɪkwɑləɾi.

"And what would you do, dear?" Daigian asked. Nynaeve wondered if she refused to call her by name on purpose, or if it was an unconscious effect of their relationship. She couldn't use "child," as she would with an actual Accepted, but to call her "Nynaeve" might imply equality.

"aɪ kəd də sʌmθɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðɪs peɪn jə fil, ɪts tə bi ən ɪfɛkt ə ðə bɑnd, ən ðɛɹfɔɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪf ðə paʊɝ kɑzəz jəɹ peɪn, ðən ðə paʊɝ kən teɪk ðət peɪn əweɪ."

"I could do something," Nynaeve said. "This pain you feel, it has to be an effect of the bond, and therefore something to do with the One Power. If the Power causes your pain, then the Power can take that pain away."

"ænd waɪ wəɾ aɪ wɑn ðæt?" deɪdʒiən æskt, ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl wʌns əɡɛn.

"And why would I want that?" Daigian asked, in control once again.

"wɛl . . . wɛl, kəz ɪts peɪn. ɪt hɝts."

"Well . . . well, because it's pain. It hurts."

"ɪt ʃʊd," deɪdʒiən sɛd. "ɛbən ɪz dɛd. wəd jə wɑnə fɝɡɛt jəɹ peɪn ɪf jə lɔs ðət hʌlkɪŋ dʒaɪən ə jʊɹz? hæv jəɹ filɪŋz fəɹ ɪm kʌɾ əweɪ laɪk səm spɔɪl tʃʌŋk ə flɛʃ ɪn ən ʌðɝwaɪz ɡʊd ɹoʊst?"

"It should," Daigian said. "Eben is dead. Would you want to forget your pain if you lost that hulking giant of yours? Have your feelings for him cut away like some spoiled chunk of flesh in an otherwise good roast?"

nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt stɑpt. wəd ʃi? ɪt wɑzn ðət sɪmpəl - hɝ filɪŋz fəɹ læn wɝ dʒɛnjəwən, ən nɑt du tə ə bɑnd. hi wɑz əɹ hʌzbənd, ən ʃi lʌv hɪm. deɪdʒiən hæd bɪn pəzɛsɪv ə hɝ wɔɹɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ði əfɛkʃən ʌv ən æn fəɹ əɹ feɪvɝd nɛfju. ɪt wɑzn ðə seɪm.

Nynaeve opened her mouth, but stopped. Would she? It wasn't that simple - her feelings for Lan were genuine, and not due to a bond. He was her husband, and she loved him. Daigian had been possessive of her Warder, but it had been the affection of an aunt for her favored nephew. It wasn't the same.

bʌt wəd nɪneɪiv wɑn ðət peɪn teɪkən əweɪ? ʃi kloʊzd əɹ maʊθ, sʌɾənli ɹilaɪzɪŋ ði ɑnɝ ɪn deɪdʒiənz wɝdz. "aɪ si. aɪm sɑɹi."

But would Nynaeve want that pain taken away? She closed her mouth, suddenly realizing the honor in Daigian's words. "I see. I'm sorry."

"ɪɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ, dɪɹ," deɪdʒiən kəntɪnjud. "ðə lɑdʒɪk ʌv ɪt simz sɪmpəl tə mi ət taɪmz, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ ðəɾ ʌðɝz də nɑɾ æksɛpt ɪt. ɪndid, səm maɪɾ ɑɹɡju ðət ðə lɑdʒɪk ə ði ɪʃu dɪpɛnz ɑn ðə moʊmən ən ði ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl. ʃæl aɪ ʃoʊ jə ðə nɛkst wiv?"

"It is nothing, dear," Daigian continued. "The logic of it seems simple to me at times, but I fear that others do not accept it. Indeed, some might argue that the logic of the issue depends on the moment and the individual. Shall I show you the next weave?"

"jɛs, pliz," nɪneɪiv sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə paʊɝ - wʌn ə ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst əlaɪv - ðət ʃi ɔfən tʊk lɪɾəl θɔt fəɹ əɹ əbɪləɾi. ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ əz ə vɛɹi tɔl mæn ɹɛɹli peɪɾ ətɛnʃən tə ʌðɝ pipəlz haɪts; ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɑz ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən hi, ən soʊ ðɛɹ dɪfɹən haɪts dɪdn mæɾɝ mʌtʃ.

"Yes, please," Nynaeve said, frowning. She herself was so strong in the Power - one of the strongest alive - that she often took little thought for her ability. It was much as a very tall man rarely paid attention to other people's heights; everyone else was shorter than he, and so their different heights didn't matter much.

wʌt wɑz ɪt laɪk tə bi ðɪs wʊmən, hu hæd spɛn lɔŋɡɝ əz ən æksɛptɪd ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪn mɛmɹi? ə wʊmən u hæd bɛɹli əteɪn ðə ʃɔl, duɪŋ soʊ - mɛni sɛd - baɪ ən aɪlæʃ ən ə wɪspɝ? deɪdʒiən hæd tə ʃoʊ dɛfɝəns tə ɔl ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪf tu sɪstɝz mɛt, deɪdʒiən wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə lɛsɝ. ɪf mɔɹ ðən tu sɪstɝz mɛt, deɪdʒiən sɝvd əm ti. bɪfɔɹ ðə mɔɹ paʊɝfəl sɪstɝz, ʃi wɑz ɪkspɛktəd tə skɹeɪp ən ɡɹɑvəl. wɛl, nɑt ðæt, ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt stɪl. . . .

What was it like to be this woman, who had spent longer as an Accepted than anyone else in memory? A woman who had barely attained the shawl, doing so - many said - by an eyelash and a whisper? Daigian had to show deference to all other Aes Sedai. If two sisters met, Daigian was always the lesser. If more than two sisters met, Daigian served them tea. Before the more powerful sisters, she was expected to scrape and grovel. Well, not that, she was Aes Sedai, but still. . . .

"ðɛɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð ðɪs sɪstəm, deɪdʒiən," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ æbsənli.

"There is something wrong with this system, Daigian," Nynaeve said absently.
