"wɪð ðə tɛstɪŋ? ɪt simz əpɹoʊpɹiət ðət ðəɹ ʃəd bi səm kaɪndə tɛs tə dətɝmən wɝðinɪs, ən ðə pɝfɔɹmɪŋ ə dɪfəkəlt wivz ʌndɝ stʃɹɛs stʃɹaɪks mi əz fʊlfɪlɪŋ ðət nid."

"With the testing? It seems appropriate that there should be some kind of test to determine worthiness, and the performing of difficult weaves under stress strikes me as fulfilling that need."

"aɪ dɪdn min ðæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "aɪ min ðə sɪstəm ðət dətɝmənz haʊ wəɹ tʃɹiɾəd. baɪ itʃ ʌðɝ."

"I didn't mean that," Nynaeve said, "I mean the system that determines how we are treated. By each other."

deɪdʒiən flʌʃt. ɪt wɑz ɪnəpɹoʊpɹiɪt tə ɹəfɝ tə ənʌðɝz paʊɝ, ɪn ɛni weɪ. bʌt, wɛl, nɪneɪiv hæd nɛvɝ bɪn vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət kənfɔɹmɪŋ tə ʌðɝ pipəlz ɛkspɛkteɪʃənz. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd fulɪʃnəs. "ðɛɹ jə sɪt," ʃi sɛd, "noʊɪŋ əz mʌtʃ əz ɛni ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ - noʊɪŋ mɔɹ ðən mɛni, aɪd weɪdʒɝ - ən ðə moʊmən ɛni æksɛptɪd dʒʌst ɔf eɪpɹən stʃɹɪŋz ɡeɪnz ðə ʃɔl, juv tə də wʌt ʃi sɛz."

Daigian flushed. It was inappropriate to refer to another's power, in any way. But, well, Nynaeve had never been very good at conforming to other people's expectations. Particularly when they expected foolishness. "There you sit," she said, "knowing as much as any other Aes Sedai - knowing more than many, I'd wager - and the moment any Accepted just off apron strings gains the shawl, you have to do what she says."

deɪdʒiənz blʌʃ dipənd. "wi ʃəd muv ɑn."

Daigian's blush deepened. "We should move on."

ɪt dʒʌst wɑzn ɹaɪt. nɪneɪiv lɛt ðə mæɾɝ dʒɹɑp, haʊɛvɝ. ʃid stɛpt ɪn ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ pɪt wʌns bɪfɔɹ ɪn titʃɪŋ ðə kɪnswɪmən tə stæn ʌp fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ðeɪd bɪn stændɪŋ ʌp tə nɪneɪiv tu, wɪtʃ hæd nɑt bɪn əɹ ɪntɛntʃən. ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən ʃi wɑntəd tə ətɛmpt ə sɪməlɝ ɹɛvəluʃən əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðɛmsɛlvz.

It just wasn't right. Nynaeve let the matter drop, however. She'd stepped in this particular pit once before in teaching the Kinswomen to stand up for themselves in front of Aes Sedai. Before long, they'd been standing up to Nynaeve too, which had not been her intention. She wasn't certain she wanted to attempt a similar revolution among the Aes Sedai themselves.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə tɝn bæk tə ðə tuɾɝɪŋ, bʌt ðət sɛns ʌv ən ɪmpɛndɪŋ stɔɹm kɛp dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ aɪz tə ðə wɪndoʊ. ðə ɹum wɑz ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ ən hæɾ ə ɡʊd vju ʌv ðə kæmp aʊtsaɪd. ɪt wɑz baɪ pjʊɹ hæpənstæns ðət nɪneɪiv kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə kædzueɪn; ðət ɡɹeɪ bʌn sɛt wɪð ɪnəsənt- lʊkɪŋ tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz ɑbviəs ivən fɹəm ə dɪstəns. ðə wʊmən wɑz kɹɔsɪŋ ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, kɔɹəl əɾ əɹ saɪd, wɔkɪŋ əɾ ə fɛɹ klɪp.

She tried to turn back to the tutoring, but that sense of an impending storm kept drawing her eyes to the window. The room was on the second floor and had a good view of the camp outside. It was by pure happenstance that Nynaeve caught a glimpse of Cadsuane; that gray bun set with innocent- looking ter'angreal was obvious even from a distance. The woman was crossing the courtyard, Corele at her side, walking at a fair clip.

wʌɾ ɪz ʃi duɪŋ? nɪneɪiv wʌndɝd. kædzueɪnz peɪs meɪɾ əɹ səspɪʃəs. wʌt hæd hæpənd? sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɹænd? ɪf ðət mæn hæd ɡɑɾən hɪmsɛlf hɝɾ əɡɛn . . .

What is she doing? Nynaeve wondered. Cadsuane's pace made her suspicious. What had happened? Something to do with Rand? If that man had gotten himself hurt again . . .

"ɪkskjus mi, deɪdʒiən," nɪneɪiv sɛd, stændɪŋ. "aɪ dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝd sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ aɪ mʌst si tə."

"Excuse me, Daigian," Nynaeve said, standing. "I just remembered something that I must see to."

ði ʌðɝ wʊmən stɑɹɾəd. "oʊ. wɛl, ɔl ɹaɪt ðɛn, nɪneɪiv. wi kən kəntɪnju ənʌðɝ taɪm, aɪ səpoʊz."

The other woman started. "Oh. Well, all right then, Nynaeve. We can continue another time, I suppose."

ɪt wɑzn əntɪl nɪneɪiv hæd hɝiɾ aʊt ðə dɔɹ ən daʊn ðə stɛɹz ðət ʃi ɹilaɪz deɪdʒiən hæɾ æktʃəli  juzd əɹ neɪm. ʃi smaɪld əz ʃi wɔkt aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɡɹin.

It wasn't until Nynaeve had hurried out the door and down the stairs that she realized Daigian had actually used her name. She smiled as she walked out onto the green.

ðəɹ wɝ il ɪn ðə kæmp. ðəɾ ɪtsɛlf wɑzn ənkɑmən; ɹænd ɔfən hæɾ ə kɑmpləmən ə meɪɾənz tə ækt əz ɡɑɹdz. bʌt ðiz il wɝ mɛn, wɛɹɪŋ ðə dʌsti bɹaʊn keɪɾɪnsɝ ən kæɹiɪŋ spɪɹz ət ðɛɹ saɪdz. ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm wɔɹ ðə hɛdbænz bɛɹɪŋ ɹændz sɪmbəl ɑn ðɛm.

There were Aiel in the camp. That itself wasn't uncommon; Rand often had a complement of Maidens to act as guards. But these Aiel were men, wearing the dusty brown cadin'sor and carrying spears at their sides. A fair number of them wore the headbands bearing Rand's symbol on them.

ðət wɑz waɪ kædzueɪn hæd bɪn ɪn sətʃ ə hɝi; ɪf ði il klæn tʃifs hæɾ ɝaɪvd, ðən ɹænd wəd bi wɑntɪŋ tə mit wɪð ðɛm. nɪneɪiv stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹin - wɪtʃ wɑzn vɛɹi ɡɹin əɾ ɔl - ɪn ə hʌf. ɹænd hædn sɛn fəɹ hɝ. pɹɑbli nɑt kəz i dɪdnt wɑnə ɪnklud hɝ, bʌt kəz i wɑz dʒʌs tu wʊl-hɛɾəd tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əɹ nɑt, ðə mæn ɹɛɹli θɔt tə ʃɛɹ ɪz plænz wɪð ʌðɝz. ʃi wʊɾə θɔt ðəɾ æftɝ ɔl ðɪs taɪm, hi wʊɾə ɹilaɪz ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ ædvaɪs fɹəm sʌmwʌn ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns ðən hi. haʊ mɛni taɪmz naʊ hæɾ i ɡɑɾən hɪmsɛlf kɪdnæpt, wundəɾ əɹ ɪmpɹɪzən kəz ə hɪz ɹæʃnəs?

That was why Cadsuane had been in such a hurry; if the Aiel clan chiefs had arrived, then Rand would be wanting to meet with them. Nynaeve strode across the green - which wasn't very green at all - in a huff. Rand hadn't sent for her. Probably not because he didn't want to include her, but because he was just too wool-headed to think of it. Dragon Reborn or not, the man rarely thought to share his plans with others. She would have thought that after all this time, he would have realized the importance of getting advice from someone a little more experienced than he. How many times now had he gotten himself kidnapped, wounded or imprisoned because of his rashness?

ɔl ðiz ʌðɝz ɪn kæmp maɪt baʊ ən skɹeɪp ən doʊɾ ɑn hɪm, bʌt nɪneɪiv nu ðəɾ i wɑz ɹɪli dʒʌst ə ʃifɝɾɝ fɹəm ɛmənz fild. hi stɪl ɡɑɾ ɪndə tʃɹʌbəl ðə seɪm weɪ hi hæd wən i ən meɪtʃɹim hæd pʊl pɹæŋks əz bɔɪz. oʊnli naʊ ɪnstɛɾ ə flʌstɝɪŋ ðə vɪlədʒ ɡɝlz i kəd θɹoʊ ɪntaɪɝ neɪʃənz ɪndə keɪɑs.

All these others in camp might bow and scrape and dote on him, but Nynaeve knew that he was really just a sheepherder from Emond's Field. He still got into trouble the same way he had when he and Matrim had pulled pranks as boys. Only now instead of flustering the village girls he could throw entire nations into chaos.

ɑn ðə fɑɹ nɔɹðɝn saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹin - dɝɛkli ɑpəzət ðə mænɝ haʊs, kloʊs tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə bʊlwɝk - ði il nukʌmɝz wɝ sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ðɛɹ kæmp, kəmplit wɪð tæn tɛns. ðeɪ ɝeɪnʒd əm dɪfɹənli ðən ðə sɑldəiənz; ɪnstɛɾ ə stʃɹeɪt ɹoʊz, ði il pɹəfɝd smɔl ɡɹups, ɔɹɡənaɪz baɪ səsaɪəɾi. səm ə bæʃɪɹz mɛn kɔld ɡɹiɾɪŋz tə pæsɪŋ il, bʌt nʌn muv tə hɛlp. il kəd bi ə pɹɪkli bʌntʃ, ən waɪl nɪneɪiv faʊn ðə sɑldəiənz tə bi fɑɹ lɛs ɪɹæʃənəl ðən moʊst, ðeɪ wɝ bɔɹɾɝləndɝz. skɝmɪʃɪz wɪð il hæd bɪn ə weɪ ʌv laɪf fəɹ əm ɪn ɝliɝ jɪɹz, ən ði il wɔɹ ɪtsɛlf wɑz nɑt soʊ dɪstənt. fəɹ naʊ, ðeɪ ɔl fɔɾ ɑn ðə seɪm saɪd, bʌt ðət dɪdn kip ðə sɑldəiənz fɹəm stɛpɪŋ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ kɛɹfəli naʊ ðət ði il hæɾ ɝaɪvd ɪn fɔɹs.

On the far northern side of the green - directly opposite the manor house, close to the front of the bulwark - the Aiel newcomers were setting up their camp, complete with tan tents. They arranged them differently than the Saldaeans; instead of straight rows, the Aiel preferred small groups, organized by society. Some of Bashere's men called greetings to passing Aiel, but none moved to help. Aiel could be a prickly bunch, and while Nynaeve found the Saldaeans to be far less irrational than most, they were Borderlanders. Skirmishes with Aiel had been a way of life for them in earlier years, and the Aiel war itself was not so distant. For now, they all fought on the same side, but that didn't keep the Saldaeans from stepping a little more carefully now that the Aiel had arrived in force.

nɪneɪiv skæn fəɹ saɪnz ə ɹænd əɹ ɛni il ʃi nu. ʃi daʊɾɪd ðəɾ eɪvinhə wəd bi wɪð ðə ɡɹup; ʃi wəd bi bæk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn wɪð ɪleɪn, hɛlpɪŋ sɪkjʊɹ ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ.

Nynaeve scanned for signs of Rand or any Aiel she knew. She doubted that Aviendha would be with the group; she would be back in Caemlyn with Elayne, helping secure the throne of Andor.

nɪneɪiv stɪl fɛlt ɡɪlti fəɹ livɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt sʌmbɑɾi hæd niɾəd tə hɛlp ɹænd klɛnz seɪɾɪn. ðət wɑzn ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ jə lɛft ɪm tə də əloʊn. naʊ, wɛɹ wɑz hi?

Nynaeve still felt guilty for leaving them, but somebody had needed to help Rand cleanse saidin. That wasn't the sort of thing you left him to do alone. Now, where was he?

nɪneɪiv stɑpt ət ðə baʊndɝi bɪtwin ðə sɑldəiənz ən ðə nu il kæmp. soʊlʒɝz kæɹiɪŋ lænsɪz nɑɾəd tə hɝ ɪn ɹɪspɛkt. il ɪn bɹaʊn ən ɡɹin ɡlaɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹæs, ðɛɹ moʊʃənz smuð əz wɔɾɝ. wɪmən ɪn bluz ən ɡɹinz kæɹid wɑʃ fɹəm ðə stʃɹim bɪsaɪd ðə mænɝ haʊs. bɹɔd-niɾəld paɪnz ʃɪvɝɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ðə kæmp bʌsəld laɪk ðə vɪlədʒ ɡɹin ət bɛl taɪn. wɪtʃ weɪ hæd kædzueɪn ɡɔn?

Nynaeve stopped at the boundary between the Saldaeans and the new Aiel camp. Soldiers carrying lances nodded to her in respect. Aiel in brown and green glided across the grass, their motions smooth as water. Women in blues and greens carried wash from the stream beside the manor house. Broad-needled pines shivered in the wind. The camp bustled like the village green at Bel Tine. Which way had Cadsuane gone?

ʃi sɛns tʃænəlɪŋ ɪn ðə nɔɹθist. nɪneɪiv smaɪld, sɛɾɪŋ ɔf wɪð ə dɪtɝmən stɛp, jɛloʊ skɝt swɪʃɪŋ. ðə tʃænəlɪŋ wəɾ iðɝ bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ ə waɪz wʌn. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, ʃi sun sɔ ə lɑɹdʒɝ il tɛn ɪɹɛktəɾ ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɡɹin. ʃi stʃɹoʊd stʃɹeɪt fəɹ ɪt, hɝ stɛɹz - əɹ pɝhæps əɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən - ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ sɑldəiən soʊlʒɝz tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ. ðə meɪɾənz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ði ɛntʃɹəns dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp hɝ.

She sensed channeling in the northeast. Nynaeve smiled, setting off with a determined step, yellow skirt swishing. The channeling would either be an Aes Sedai or a Wise One. Sure enough, she soon saw a larger Aiel tent erected at the corner of the green. She strode straight for it, her stares - or perhaps her reputation - encouraging Saldaean soldiers to get out of her way. The Maidens guarding the entrance did not try to stop her.

ɹænd stʊɾ ɪnsaɪd, wɛɹɪŋ blæk ən ɹɛd, lifɪŋ θɹu mæps ɑn ə stɝɾi wʊɾən teɪbəl, hɪz lɛft ɑɹm hɛl bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. bæʃɪɹ stʊɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd, nɑɾɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf ən stʌɾiɪŋ ə smɔl mæp i hɛl bɪfɔɹ hɪm.

Rand stood inside, wearing black and red, leafing through maps on a sturdy wooden table, his left arm held behind his back. Bashere stood at his side, nodding to himself and studying a small map he held before him.

ɹænd lʊkt ʌp əz nɪneɪiv ɛntɝd. wən hæɾ i stɑɹɾəd lʊkɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ laɪk ə wɔɹɾɝ, wɪð ðəɾ ɪnstənt ɡlæns ʌv əsɛsmənt? ðoʊz aɪz wɪtʃ pɪkt aʊɾ ɛvɹi θɹɛt, bɑɾi tɛns əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ən ətæk əɾ ɛni taɪm? aɪ ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛt ðət wʊmən teɪk ɪm fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ʃi θɔt. lʊk wʌɾ ɪts dʌn tə hɪm.

Rand looked up as Nynaeve entered. When had he started looking so much like a Warder, with that instant glance of assessment? Those eyes which picked out every threat, body tense as if expecting an attack at any time? I should never have let that woman take him from the Two Rivers, she thought. Look what it's done to him.

ʃi ɪmiɾiətli fɹaʊn əɾ əɹ oʊn fulɪʃnəs. ɪf ɹænd hæd steɪɾ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, hi wʊɾə ɡɔn mæɾ ən pɝhæps dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ əm ɔl - əsumɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, ðə tʃɹɑləks, ðə feɪdz əɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən ðɛmsɛlvz hædn əkɑmplɪʃt ðə tæsk fɝst. ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn hædn kʌm fəɹ ɹænd, hid naʊ bi dɛd. wɪð ɪm wʊɾə ɡɔn ðə laɪɾ ən hoʊp ə ðə wɝld. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs hɑɹd tə əbændən əɹ oʊl pɹɛdʒəɾɪsɪz.

She immediately frowned at her own foolishness. If Rand had stayed in the Two Rivers, he would have gone mad and perhaps destroyed them all - assuming, of course, the Trollocs, the Fades or the Forsaken themselves hadn't accomplished the task first. If Moiraine hadn't come for Rand, he'd now be dead. With him would have gone the light and hope of the world. It was just hard to abandon her old prejudices.

"ɑ, nɪneɪiv," ɹænd sɛd, ɹɪlæksɪŋ ən tɝnɪŋ bæk tə hɪz mæps. hi moʊʃən fəɹ bæʃɪɹ tə ɪnspɛkt wʌn ə ðɛm, ðən tɝn bæk tə hɝ. "aɪ wɑz əbaʊt tə sɛn fəɹ ju. ɹəɑɹk ən beɪl ɑɹ hɪɹ."

"Ah, Nynaeve," Rand said, relaxing and turning back to his maps. He motioned for Bashere to inspect one of them, then turned back to her. "I was about to send for you. Rhuarc and Bael are here."

nɪneɪiv ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "oʊ?" ʃi æsk flætli. "æn hɪɹ aɪɾ əsum ðəɾ ɔl ði il ɪn ðə kæmp mɛnt wi hæd bɪn ətæk baɪ ʃeɪɾoʊ."

Nynaeve raised an eyebrow, folding her arms. "Oh?" she asked flatly. "And here I'd assumed that all the Aiel in the camp meant we had been attacked by Shaido."

hɪz feɪs hɑɹɾənd əɾ əɹ toʊn, ən ðoʊz aɪz ə hɪz ɡɹu . . . deɪnʒɝəs. bʌt ðən i laɪɾənd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf tə klɪɹ ɪt. səm ə ði oʊld ɹænd - ðə ɹænd u hæd bɪn ən ɪnəsənt ʃifɝɾɝ - sim tə ɹɪtɝn. "jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs jə wəɾ əv noʊɾəst," hi sɛd. "aɪm ɡlæd jə ɑɹ hɪɹ. wɪl bɪɡɪn əz sun əz ðə klæn tʃifs ɹɪtɝn. aɪ ɪnsɪstəd ðeɪ si ðɛɹ pipəl sɛɾəld bɪfɔɹ wi bɪɡæn."

His face hardened at her tone, and those eyes of his grew . . . dangerous. But then he lightened, shaking his head, almost as if to clear it. Some of the old Rand - the Rand who had been an innocent sheepherder - seemed to return. "Yes, of course you would have noticed," he said. "I'm glad you are here. We will begin as soon as the clan chiefs return. I insisted they see their people settled before we began."

hi weɪv fəɹ əɹ tə sɪt; ðəɹ wɝ kʊʃənz ɑn ðə flɔɹ, bʌt noʊ tʃɛɹz. il spɝn ðoʊz, ən ɹænd wəd wɑn əm tə bi kʌmftəɹbəl. nɪneɪiv aɪd hɪm, sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ taɪɾ əɹ oʊn nɝvz hæd bɪkʌm. hi wɑz dʒʌst ə wʊl-hɛɾəd vɪlɪdʒɝ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mʌtʃ ɪnfluəns hid faʊnd. hi wɑz.

He waved for her to sit; there were cushions on the floor, but no chairs. Aiel spurned those, and Rand would want them to be comfortable. Nynaeve eyed him, surprised at how tight her own nerves had become. He was just a wool-headed villager, no matter how much influence he'd found. He was.

bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt ʃeɪk əweɪ ðət lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪz, ðət flæʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ. hoʊldɪŋ ə kɹaʊn wɑz sɛd tə tʃeɪnʒ mɛni mɛn fəɹ ðə wɝs. ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə si ðət dɪdn hæpən tə ɹænd ælθɹ, bʌt wʌt ɹikɔɹs wəd ʃi hæv ɪf i sʌɾənli dɪsaɪɾɪd tə hæv əɹ ɪmpɹɪzənd? hi wʊdn də ðæt, wəd hi? nɑt ɹænd.

But she could not shake away that look in his eyes, that flash of anger. Holding a crown was said to change many men for the worse. She intended to see that didn't happen to Rand al'Thor, but what recourse would she have if he suddenly decided to have her imprisoned? He wouldn't do that, would he? Not Rand.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛɾ i wɑz mæd, nɪneɪiv θɔt. sɛd ðət . . . hi hɝd vɔɪsəz fɹəm ɪz pæs laɪf.

Semirhage said he was mad, Nynaeve thought. Said that . . . he heard voices from his past life.

ɪz ðət wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ wən i kɑks ɪz hɛd, əz ɪf lɪsnɪŋ tə θɪŋz ðət noʊbɑdi ɛls kən hɪɹ?

Is that what is happening when he cocks his head, as if listening to things that nobody else can hear?

ʃi ʃɪvɝd. mɪn wɑz ðəɹ ɪn ðə tɛnt, ʌv kɔɹs, sɪɾɪŋ ən ɹiɾɪŋ ə bʊk ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ: ðə weɪk ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ. mɪn lʊk tu ɪntɛnli ət ðə peɪdʒəz; ʃid lɪsən tə ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ bɪtwin ɹænd ən nɪneɪiv. wʌd ʃi θɪŋk ə ðə tʃeɪnʒəz ɪn hɪm? ʃi wɑz kloʊsɝ tə hɪm ðən ɛniwʌn -  kloʊs ɪnʌf ðæt, ɪf ðeɪɾ ɔl bɪn bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, nɪneɪiv wʊɾə ɡɪvən ðə tu ʌv əm ə tʌŋ-læʃɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðɛɹ hɛdz spɪn. ivən ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝn ɪn ɛmənz fild ən ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɪzdəm, ʃid meɪd sɝɾən ðət ɹænd nu ʌv əɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ. hɪz ɹɪspɑns hæd bɪn sɪmpəl: "ɪf aɪ mɛɹi hɝ, maɪ dɛθ wɪl bɹɪŋ əɹ ivən mɔɹ peɪn."

She shivered. Min was there in the tent, of course, sitting and reading a book in the corner: The Wake of the Breaking. Min looked too intently at the pages; she'd listened to the exchange between Rand and Nynaeve. What did she think of the changes in him? She was closer to him than anyone -  close enough that, if they'd all been back in Emond's Field, Nynaeve would have given the two of them a tongue-lashing strong enough to make their heads spin. Even though they weren't in Emond's Field and she was no longer Wisdom, she'd made certain that Rand knew of her displeasure. His response had been simple: "If I marry her, my death will bring her even more pain."

mɔɹ ɪɾiəsi, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪf jə wɝ plænɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ɪndə deɪnʒɝ, ðən ɪt wɑz ɔl ðə mɔɹ ɹizən tə ɡɛt mɛɹid. ɑbviəsli. nɪneɪiv siɾəd hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ skɝts, ən pɔɪntɪdli dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə læn. hi hæd sətʃ ə lɔŋ dɪstəns tə kʌvɝ, ænd. . . .

More idiocy, of course. If you were planning to go into danger, then it was all the more reason to get married. Obviously. Nynaeve seated herself on the floor, arranging her skirts, and pointedly did not think of Lan. He had such a long distance to cover, and. . . .

ən ʃi hæd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət ʃi wɑz ɡɪvən ɪz bɑn bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ðə blaɪt. dʒʌst ɪn keɪs.

And she had to make sure that she was given his bond before he reached the Blight. Just in case.

sʌɾənli, ʃi sæɾ əpɹaɪt. kædzueɪn. ðə wʊmən wɑzn ðɛɹ; bɪsaɪdz ɡɑɹdz, ðə tɛn kənteɪn oʊnli ɹænd, nɪneɪiv, mɪn ən bæʃɪɹ. wɑz ʃi ɔf plænɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ðət nɪneɪiv -  kædzueɪn ɛntɝd. ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɔɹ ə sɪmpəl tæn dʒɹɛs. ʃi ɹɪlaɪɾ ɑn pɹɛzəns, nɑt kloʊðɪŋ, tə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən, ən ə kɔɹs əɹ hɛɹ spɑɹkəld wɪð ɪts ɡoʊldən ɔɹnəməns. kɔɹəl fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪn.

Suddenly, she sat upright. Cadsuane. The woman wasn't there; besides guards, the tent contained only Rand, Nynaeve, Min and Bashere. Was she off planning something that Nynaeve -  Cadsuane entered. The gray-haired Aes Sedai wore a simple tan dress. She relied on presence, not clothing, to draw attention, and of course her hair sparkled with its golden ornaments. Corele followed her in.

kædzueɪn woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, ən ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ əbdʒɛkt. hi ʃəd stɪk ʌp fəɹ hɪmsɛlf mɔɹ - ðət wʊmən pɹæktəkli hæɾ ɪm teɪmd, ən ɪt wɑz ənsɛɾəlɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ i lɛɾ əɹ ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð. laɪk kwɛstʃənɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒ. ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɝ fɑɹ tu paʊɝfəl ən deɪnʒɝəs tə tʃɹit laɪtli. sɛmɝhɪdʒ ʃʊɾə bɪn stɪl ðə moʊmən ðeɪ kæptʃɝɾ əɹ . . . ðoʊ nɪneɪivz əpɪnjən ɪn ðət ɹəɡɑɹd wɑz dɝɛkli ɹɪleɪɾɪd tə hɝ oʊn ɪkspɪɹiəns ɪn kipɪŋ mɑɡiɾin kæptɪv.

Cadsuane wove a ward against eavesdropping, and Rand did not object. He should stick up for himself more - that woman practically had him tamed, and it was unsettling how much he let her get away with. Like questioning Semirhage. The Forsaken were far too powerful and dangerous to treat lightly. Semirhage should have been stilled the moment they captured her . . . though Nynaeve's opinion in that regard was directly related to her own experience in keeping Moghedien captive.

kɔɹəl ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ə smaɪl; ʃi tɛndəd tə hæv wʌn ə ðoʊz fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn. kædzueɪn, əz juʒəwəl, ɪɡnɔɹd nɪneɪiv. ðət wɑz faɪn. nɪneɪiv hæd noʊ nid fəɹ əɹ əpɹuvəl. kædzueɪn θɔt ʃi kəɾ ɔɹɾɝ ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn dʒʌs kəz ʃiɾ aʊtlɪvd ɛvɹi ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɛl, nɪneɪiv nu fəɹ ə fæk ðəɾ eɪdʒ hæd lɪɾəl tə də wɪð wɪzdəm. sɛn bui hæd bɪn əz oʊld əz ɹeɪn, bʌt hæɾ əbaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ sɛns əz ə paɪl ə ɹɑks.

Corele gave Nynaeve a smile; she tended to have one of those for everyone. Cadsuane, as usual, ignored Nynaeve. That was fine. Nynaeve had no need for her approval. Cadsuane thought she could order everyone around just because she'd outlived every other Aes Sedai. Well, Nynaeve knew for a fact that age had little to do with wisdom. Cenn Buie had been as old as rain, but had about as much sense as a pile of rocks.

mɛni ʌv ðə kæmps ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən kæmp liɾɝz tʃɹɪkəld ɪndə ðə tɛn oʊvɝ ðə nɛks fju mɪnəts; pɝhæps ɹænd ɹɪli hæd sɛn mɛsənʒɝz, ən wʊɾə kɔl fəɹ nɪneɪiv. ðə nukʌmɝz ɪnkluɾəd mɛɹaɪs ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝz, wʌn ə hum wɑz ði æʃəmən dʒɑhɹ nɛɹɪʃmə, bɛlz tɪŋkəlɪŋ ɑn ði ɛnz ə hɪz bɹeɪdz. deɪmɝ flɪn, ɛlzə pɛnfəl, ə fju ʌv bæʃɪɹz ɔfəsɝz ɔlsoʊ ɝaɪvd.

Many of the camp's other Aes Sedai and camp leaders trickled into the tent over the next few minutes; perhaps Rand really had sent messengers, and would have called for Nynaeve. The newcomers included Merise and her Warders, one of whom was the Asha'man Jahar Narishma, bells tinkling on the ends of his braids. Damer Flinn, Elza Penfell, a few of Bashere's officers also arrived.

ɹænd ɡlænst ʌp wən itʃ wʌn ɛntɝd, əlɝɾ ən wɛɹi, bʌɾ i kwɪkli tɝn bæk tə hɪz mæps. wɑz i ɡɹoʊɪŋ pɛɹənɔɪd? səm mædmən ɡɹu səspɪʃəs ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn.

Rand glanced up when each one entered, alert and wary, but he quickly turned back to his maps. Was he growing paranoid? Some madmen grew suspicious of everyone.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɹəɑɹk ən beɪl meɪd ðɛɹ əpɪɹəns, əlɔŋ wɪð sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ il. ðeɪ stɔk θɹu ðə tɛns lɑɹdʒ ɛntʃɹəns laɪk kæts ɑn ðə pɹaʊl. ɪn ən ɑd tɝn, ə bætʃ ʌv waɪz wʌnz - hum nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə sɛns wən ðeɪ ɡɑt kloʊs - wɝ əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹup. ɔfən, wɪð il, ən ɪvɛnt wɑz iðɝ kənsɪɾɝd klæn tʃif bɪznəs əɹ waɪz wʌn bɪznəs - mʌtʃ əz θɪŋz hæpən bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪð ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl ən ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl. hæd ɹænd æsk fəɹ əm ɔl tə ətɛnd, əɹ hæd ðeɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə kʌm təɡɛðɝ fəɹ ɹizənz ə ðɛɹ oʊn?

Eventually, Rhuarc and Bael made their appearance, along with several other Aiel. They stalked through the tent's large entrance like cats on the prowl. In an odd turn, a batch of Wise Ones - whom Nynaeve had been able to sense when they got close - were among the group. Often, with Aiel, an event was either considered clan chief business or Wise One business - much as things happened back in the Two Rivers with the Village Council and the Women's Circle. Had Rand asked for them all to attend, or had they decided to come together for reasons of their own?

nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ əbaʊɾ eɪvinhəz loʊkeɪʃən; ʃi wɑz ʃɑk tə si ðə tɔl, ɹɛd-hɛɹd wʊmən hʌvɝɪŋ ət ðə bæk ə ðə ɡɹup ʌv waɪz wʌnz. wən hæd ʃi lɛf keɪɛmlɪn? ən waɪ wɑz ʃi kæɹiɪŋ ðət wɔɹn klɔθ wɪð ə fɹeɪɾ ɛdʒ?

Nynaeve had been wrong about Aviendha's location; she was shocked to see the tall, red-haired woman hovering at the back of the group of Wise Ones. When had she left Caemlyn? And why was she carrying that worn cloth with a frayed edge?

nɪneɪiv dɪdnt ɡɛɾ ə tʃæns tə æsk eɪvinhə ɛni kwɛstʃənz, əz ɹænd nɑɾəd tə ɹəɑɹk ən ði ʌðɝz, moʊʃənɪŋ fəɹ əm tə sɪt, wɪtʃ ðeɪ dɪd. ɹænd hɪmsɛlf ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz mæp teɪbəl. hi pleɪst ɪz ɑɹmz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, hæn klæspɪŋ stʌmp, ə θɔtfəl lʊk ɑn ɪz feɪs. hi ɔfɝd noʊ pɹiæmbəl. "tɛl mi ʌv jəɹ wɝk ɪn ɑɹæd dumən," hi sɛd tə ɹəɑɹk. "maɪ skaʊts ɪnfɔɹm mi ðət ðɪs læn ɪz hɑɹdli ət pis."

Nynaeve didn't get a chance to ask Aviendha any questions, as Rand nodded to Rhuarc and the others, motioning for them to sit, which they did. Rand himself remained standing beside his map table. He placed his arms behind his back, hand clasping stump, a thoughtful look on his face. He offered no preamble. "Tell me of your work in Arad Doman," he said to Rhuarc. "My scouts inform me that this land is hardly at peace."

ɹəɑɹk æksɛptɪɾ ə kʌp ə ti fɹəm eɪvinhə - soʊ ʃi wɑz stɪl kənsɪɾɝd ən əpɹɛntəs - ən tɝn tə ɹænd. ðə klæn tʃif dɪd nɑt dʒɹɪŋk. "wi hæv hæd vɛɹi lɪɾəl taɪm, ɹænd ælθɹ."

Rhuarc accepted a cup of tea from Aviendha - so she was still considered an apprentice - and turned to Rand. The clan chief did not drink. "We have had very little time, Rand al'Thor."

"aɪ doʊn lʊk fəɹ ɪkskjusɪz, ɹəɑɹk," ɹænd sɛd. "oʊnli ɹɪzʌls."

"I don't look for excuses, Rhuarc," Rand said. "Only results."

ðɪs bɹɔt flæʃɪz ʌv æŋɡɝ tə ðə feɪsəz ə sɛvɹəl ə ði ʌðɝ il, ən ðə meɪɾənz ət ðə dɔɹweɪ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə fjʊɹiəs bɝst ə hæn sɪɡnəlz.

This brought flashes of anger to the faces of several of the other Aiel, and the Maidens at the doorway exchanged a furious burst of hand signals.

ɹəɑɹk hɪmsɛlf dɪspleɪd noʊ æŋɡɝ, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv dɪd θɪŋk ɪz hæn taɪɾənd ɑn ɪz kʌp. "aɪ hæv ʃɛɹd wɔɾɝ wɪð ju, ɹænd ælθɹ," hi sɛd. "aɪ wəd nɑt θɪŋk ðət jə wəd bɹɪŋ mi hɪɹ tə ɔfɝ ɪnsʌls."

Rhuarc himself displayed no anger, though Nynaeve did think his hand tightened on his cup. "I have shared water with you, Rand al'Thor," he said. "I would not think that you would bring me here to offer insults."

"noʊ ɪnsʌls, ɹəɑɹk," ɹænd sɛd. "dʒʌs tʃɹuθs. wi doʊn əv taɪm tə weɪst."

"No insults, Rhuarc," Rand said. "Just truths. We don't have time to waste."

"noʊ taɪm, ɹænd ælθɹ?" beɪl sɛd. ðə klæn tʃif ə ðə ɡoʊʃin il wɑz ə vɛɹi tɔl mæn, ən i sim tə taʊɝ, ivən wən sɪɾɪŋ daʊn. "ju lɛf mɛni ʌv əs ɪn ændɝ fəɹ mʌnθs wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə də bʌt pɑlɪʃ spɪɹz ən skɛɹ wɛtləndɝz! naʊ jə sɛn əs tə ðɪs lænd wɪð ɪmpɑsəbəl ɔɹɾɝz, ðən fɑloʊ ə fju wiks leɪɾɝ ən dɪmæn ɹɪzʌls?"

"No time, Rand al'Thor?" Bael said. The clan chief of the Goshien Aiel was a very tall man, and he seemed to tower, even when sitting down. "You left many of us in Andor for months with nothing to do but polish spears and scare wetlanders! Now you send us to this land with impossible orders, then follow a few weeks later and demand results?"

"ju wɝ ɪn ændɝ tə hɛlp ɪleɪn," ɹænd sɛd.

"You were in Andor to help Elayne," Rand said.

"ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ nid hɛlp," beɪl sɛd wɪð ə snɔɹt. "ænd ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt tə ɹəfjuz eɪd. aɪd ɹæðɝ ɹʌn əkɹɔs ði ɪntaɪɝ weɪst wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl skɪn ʌv wɔɾɝ ðən əv liɾɝʃɪp ə maɪ klæn hændəd tə mi baɪ ənʌðɝ."

"She did not want or need help," Bael said with a snort. "And she was right to refuse aid. I'd rather run across the entire Waste with a single skin of water than have leadership of my clan handed to me by another."

ɹændz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu dɑɹk əɡɛn, hɪz aɪz stɔɹmi, ən nɪneɪiv wɑz əɡɛn ɹimaɪndəɾ ə ðə tɛmpəs bɹuɪŋ tə ðə nɔɹθ.

Rand's expression grew dark again, his eyes stormy, and Nynaeve was again reminded of the tempest brewing to the north.

"ðɪs læn ɪz bɹoʊkən, ɹænd ælθɹ," ɹəɑɹk sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs kɑmɝ ðən beɪlz. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt meɪkɪŋ ɪkskjusɪz tə ɪkspleɪn ðət fækt, ən ɪts nɑt kaʊɝɾəs tə bi kɔʃəs əbaʊɾ ə dɪfəkəl tæsk."

"This land is broken, Rand al'Thor," Rhuarc said, his voice calmer than Bael's. "It is not making excuses to explain that fact, and it is not cowardice to be cautious about a difficult task."

"wi mʌst əv pis hɪɹ," ɹænd ɡɹaʊld. "ɪf jə kæn mænədʒ - "

"We must have peace here," Rand growled. "If you can't manage - "

"bɔɪ," kædzueɪn sɛd, "pɝhæps jə wɑnə stɑp ən θɪŋk. haʊ ɔfən əv jə noʊn ði il tə feɪl ju? haʊ ɔfən əv jə feɪld, hɝt, əɹ əfɛndəd ðɛm?"

"Boy," Cadsuane said, "perhaps you want to stop and think. How often have you known the Aiel to fail you? How often have you failed, hurt, or offended them?"

ɹænd snæpt ɪz maʊθ kloʊzd, ən nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ ət nɑt hævɪŋ spoʊkən ʌp hɝsɛlf.

Rand snapped his mouth closed, and Nynaeve gritted her teeth at not having spoken up herself.

ʃi ɡlænst ət kædzueɪn, hu hæd bɪn ɡɪvən ə tʃɛɹ tə sɪɾ əpɑn - nɪneɪiv kʊdn ɹikɔl ɛvɝ siɪŋ əɹ sɪɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðə tʃɛɹ hæɾ ɑbviəsli bɪn teɪkən fɹəm ðə mænɝ; ɪt wɑz kənstʃɹʌktəd fɹəm peɪl ɛldʒɪlɹɪm hɔɹnz - wɪtʃ stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt laɪk oʊpən pɑmz - ən hæɾ ə ɹɛd kʊʃən. eɪvinhə hændəd kædzueɪn ə kʌp ə ti, wɪtʃ ʃi sɪp kɛɹfəli.

She glanced at Cadsuane, who had been given a chair to sit upon - Nynaeve couldn't recall ever seeing her sit on the floor. The chair had obviously been taken from the manor; it was constructed from pale elgilrim horns - which stretched out like open palms - and had a red cushion. Aviendha handed Cadsuane a cup of tea, which she sipped carefully.

wɪð ɑbviəs ɛfɝt, ɹænd pʊld ɪz tɛmpɝ bæk ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. "aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz, ɹəɑɹk, beɪl. ɪts bɪn ə . . . wɛɹɪŋ fju mʌnθs."

With obvious effort, Rand pulled his temper back under control. "I apologize, Rhuarc, Bael. It has been a . . . wearing few months."

"ju hæv noʊ toʊ," ɹəɑɹk sɛd. "bʌt pliz, sɪt. lɛɾ əs ʃɛɹ ʃeɪɾ ən spik wɪð səvɪləɾi."

"You have no toh," Rhuarc said. "But please, sit. Let us share shade and speak with civility."

ɹænd saɪɾ ɑɾəbli, ðən nɑɾəd, siɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝ tu. ðə sɛvɹəl waɪz wʌnz ɪn ətɛndəns - æmɪz, məleɪn, bɛɹ - dɪdn sim ɪnklaɪn tə pɑɹtɪsəpeɪɾ ɪn ðə dɪskʌʃən. ðeɪ wɝ əbzɝvɝz, mʌtʃ - nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪzd - əz ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz.

Rand sighed audibly, then nodded, seating himself before the other two. The several Wise Ones in attendance - Amys, Melaine, Bair - didn't seem inclined to participate in the discussion. They were observers, much - Nynaeve realized - as she herself was.

"wi mʌst əv pis ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, maɪ fɹɛnz," ɹænd sɛd, ənɹoʊlɪŋ ə mæp bɪtwin əm ɑn ðə tɛn ɹʌɡ.

"We must have peace in Arad Doman, my friends," Rand said, unrolling a map between them on the tent rug.

beɪl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "dɑbɹeɪn tæbɔɹwɪn əz dʌn wɛl wɪð bændɑɹ ɛbən," hi sɛd, "bʌt ɹəɑɹk spoʊk ɹaɪtli wən i kɔl ðɪs læn bɹoʊkən. ɪts laɪk ə pis ə si foʊk pɔɹsələn dʒɹɑp fɹəm ðə tɪp ʌv ə haɪ maʊntən. jə toʊld əs tə dɪskʌvɝ u wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ən si ɪf wi kəd ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ. wɛl, əz fɑɹ əz wi kən tɛl, noʊ wʌn ɪz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ. itʃ sɪɾi hæz bɪn lɛf tə fɛn fəɹ ɪtsɛlf."

Bael shook his head. "Dobraine Taborwin has done well with Bandar Eban," he said, "but Rhuarc spoke rightly when he called this land broken. It is like a piece of Sea Folk porcelain dropped from the tip of a high mountain. You told us to discover who was in charge and see if we could restore order. Well, as far as we can tell, no one is in charge. Each city has been left to fend for itself."

"wʌɾ ə ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns?" bæʃɪɹ sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn wɪð ðɛm, nʌklɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃ əz i stʌɾid ðə mæp. "maɪ skaʊts seɪ ðət ðeɪ stɪl hoʊl səm mɛʒɝ ə paʊɝ."

"What of the Council of Merchants?" Bashere said, sitting down with them, knuckling his mustache as he studied the map. "My scouts say that they still hold some measure of power."

"ɪn ðə sɪɾiz wɛɹ ðeɪ ɹul, ðɪs ɪz tʃɹu," ɹəɑɹk sɛd. "bʌt ðɛɹ ɪnfluəns ɪz wik. ðəɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn mɛmbɝ stɪl ɪn ðə kæpəɾəl, ən ʃiz lɪɾəl kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛɹ. wɪv stɑp ðə faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹits, bʌɾ oʊnli wɪð ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝt." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðɪs ɪz wʌt kʌmz fɹəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl mɔɹ lænz ðən hoʊlz ən klæn. wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ kɪŋ, ðiz dəmɑni də nɑt noʊ hu ɪz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ."

"In the cities where they rule, this is true," Rhuarc said. "But their influence is weak. There is only one member still in the capital, and she has little control there. We have stopped the fighting in the streets, but only with great effort." He shook his head. "This is what comes from trying to control more lands than holds and clan. Without their king, these Domani do not know who is in charge."

"wɛɹ ɪz hi?" ɹænd æskt.

"Where is he?" Rand asked.

"noʊbɑdi noʊz, ɹænd ælθɹ. hi vænɪʃt. səm seɪ mʌnθs əɡoʊ, ʌðɝz seɪ ɪts bɪn jɪɹz."

"Nobody knows, Rand al'Thor. He vanished. Some say months ago, others say it has been years."

"ɡɹeɪndəl maɪɾ əv hɪm," ɹænd wɪspɝd, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə mæp ɪntɛnli. "ɪf ʃiz hɪɹ. jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk ʃi pɹɑbli ɪz. bʌt wɛɹ? ʃi woʊn bi ɪn ðə kɪŋz pæləs, ðæts nɑɾ əɹ weɪ. ʃɪl əv səm pleɪs ðəɾ ɪz hɝz, ə pleɪs wɛɹ ʃi kən dɪspleɪ hɝ tʃɹoʊfiz. ə loʊkeɪʃən ðət wəd meɪk ə tʃɹoʊfi ɪtsɛlf, bʌt nɑɾ ə pleɪs ðət wʌn wəd θɪŋk ʌv ɪmiɾiətli. jɛs, aɪ noʊ. jəɹ ɹaɪt. ðæts haʊ ʃi dɪɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ. . . ."

"Graendal might have him," Rand whispered, studying the map intently. "If she's here. Yes, I think she probably is. But where? She won't be in the king's palace, that's not her way. She will have some place that is hers, a place where she can display her trophies. A location that would make a trophy itself, but not a place that one would think of immediately. Yes, I know. You're right. That's how she did it before. . . ."

sətʃ fəmɪljɛɹəɾi! nɪneɪiv ʃɪvɝd. eɪvinhə nɛl bɪsaɪd hɝ, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ə kʌp ə ti. nɪneɪiv tʊk ɪt, miɾɪŋ ðə wʊmənz aɪz, ðən bɪɡæn tə wɪspɝ ə kwɛstʃən. eɪvinhə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd kɝtli.

Such familiarity! Nynaeve shivered. Aviendha knelt beside her, holding out a cup of tea. Nynaeve took it, meeting the woman's eyes, then began to whisper a question. Aviendha shook her head curtly.

leɪɾɝ, hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən sim tə ɪmplaɪ. eɪvinhə ɹoʊz ən ɹitʃɹiɾəd tə ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum ən ðɛn, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, tʊk aʊɾ əɹ fɹeɪd klɔθ ən bɪɡæn pʊlɪŋ ðə θɹɛdz aʊt wʌn əɾ ə taɪm. wʌt wɑz ðə pɔɪn ə ðæt?

Later, her expression seemed to imply. Aviendha rose and retreated to the back of the room and then, grimacing, took out her frayed cloth and began pulling the threads out one at a time. What was the point of that?

"kædzueɪn," ɹænd sɛd, stɑpɪŋ ɪz wɪspɝɪŋ, spikɪŋ ʌp. "wʌt dʒju noʊ ʌv ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns?"

"Cadsuane," Rand said, stopping his whispering, speaking up. "What do you know of the Council of Merchants?"

"ðeɪ ɑɹ moʊsli wɪmən," kædzueɪn sɛd, "ænd wɪmən ʌv ɡɹeɪt kʌnɪŋ ət ðæt. haʊɛvɝ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔlsoʊ ə sɛlfɪʃ lɑt. ɪts ðɛɹ duɾi tə tʃuz ðə kɪŋ, ən wɪð ælsələmz dɪsəpɪɹəns, ðeɪ ʃʊɾə faʊn ə ɹɪpleɪsmənt. tu mɛni ʌv əm si ðɪs əz ən ɑpɝtunəɾi, ən ðət kips əm fɹəm ɹitʃɪŋ ən əɡɹimənt. aɪ kən əsum ðət ðeɪv sɛpɝeɪɾəd ɪn feɪs ə ðɪs keɪɑs tə sɪkjʊɹ paʊɝ ɪn ðɛɹ hoʊm sɪɾiz, faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ pəzɪʃən ən əlaɪənsəz əz ðeɪ itʃ ɔfɝ ðɛɹ oʊn tʃɔɪs ə kɪŋ fəɹ ði ʌðɝz tə kənsɪɾɝ."

"They are mostly women," Cadsuane said, "and women of great cunning at that. However, they are also a selfish lot. It is their duty to choose the king, and with Alsalam's disappearance, they should have found a replacement. Too many of them see this as an opportunity, and that keeps them from reaching an agreement. I can assume that they've separated in face of this chaos to secure power in their home cities, fighting for position and alliances as they each offer their own choice of king for the others to consider."

"æn ðɪs dəmɑni ɑɹmi faɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn?" ɹænd æskt. "ɪz ðət ðɛɹ duɪŋ?"

"And this Domani army fighting the Seanchan?" Rand asked. "Is that their doing?"

"aɪ noʊ nʌθɪŋ ə ðæt."

"I know nothing of that."

"ju spik ə ðə mæn ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi," ɹəɑɹk sɛd.

"You speak of the man Rodel Ituralde," Rhuarc said.

"jɛs."

"Yes."

"hi fɔt wɛl twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ," ɹəɑɹk sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz skwɛɹ tʃɪn. "hi ɪz ə ðə wʌnz jə kɔl ə ɡɹeɪt kæptən. aɪ ʃəd laɪk tə dæns ðə spɪɹz wɪð hɪm."

"He fought well twenty years ago," Rhuarc said, rubbing his square chin. "He is of the ones you call a Great Captain. I should like to dance the spears with him."

"ju wɪl nɑt," ɹænd sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "nɑt waɪl aɪ lɪv, ət list. wɪl sɪkjʊɹ ðɪs lænd."

"You will not," Rand said sharply. "Not while I live, at least. We will secure this land."

"æn jə ɪkspɛkt əs tə də ðɪs wɪθaʊt faɪɾɪŋ?" beɪl æskt. "ðɪs ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi ɹɪpɔɹɾədli faɪts laɪk ə sændstɔɹm əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn, dʒɹɔɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪɹ bɛɾɝ - ivən - ðən jə jɝsɛlf, ɹænd ælθɹ. hɪl nɑt slip waɪl jə kɑŋkɝ ɪz hoʊmlænd."

"And you expect us to do this without fighting?" Bael asked. "This Rodel Ituralde reportedly fights like a sandstorm against the Seanchan, drawing their ire better - even - than you yourself, Rand al'Thor. He will not sleep while you conquer his homeland."

"wʌns əɡɛn," ɹænd sɛd, "wi ɑɹ nɑt hɪɹ tə kɑŋkɝ."

"Once again," Rand said, "we are not here to conquer."

ɹəɑɹk saɪd. "ðɛn waɪ sɛn ʌs, ɹænd ælθɹ? waɪ nɑt juz jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ? ðeɪ ʌndɝstænd wɛtləndɝz. ðɪs kʌntʃɹi ɪz laɪk ən ɪntaɪɝ kɪŋdəm ə tʃɪlʒɹən, ən wəɹ tu fju ədʌls tə bɹɪŋ əm tə oʊbiɾiəns. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪf jə fɝbɪɾ əs tə spæŋk ðɛm."

Rhuarc sighed. "Then why send us, Rand al'Thor? Why not use your Aes Sedai? They understand wetlanders. This country is like an entire kingdom of children, and we are too few adults to bring them to obedience. Particularly if you forbid us to spank them."

"ju kən faɪt," ɹænd sɛd, "bʌɾ oʊnli wən jə nid tə. ɹəɑɹk, ðɪs əz ɡɔn bɪɑn ði əbɪləɾi ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ tə fɪks. jə kən də ðɪs. pipəl ɑɹ ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd baɪ ði il; ðəl də əz jə seɪ. ɪf wi kən stɑp ðə dəmɑni wɔɹ wɪð ðə sintʃæn, pɝhæps ðɪs dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz wɪl si ðəɾ aɪm sɪɹiəs ɪn maɪ dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ pis. ðən meɪbi ʃɪl əɡɹi tə mit wɪð mi."

"You can fight," Rand said, "but only when you need to. Rhuarc, this has gone beyond the ability of Aes Sedai to fix. You can do this. People are intimidated by the Aiel; they will do as you say. If we can stop the Domani war with the Seanchan, perhaps this Daughter of the Nine Moons will see that I am serious in my desire for peace. Then maybe she'll agree to meet with me."

"waɪ nɑt də əz juv dʌn bɪfɔɹ?" beɪl æskt. "siz ðə læn fəɹ jəɹ oʊn?"

"Why not do as you've done before?" Bael asked. "Seize the land for your own?"

bæʃɪɹ nɑɾəd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ɹænd.

Bashere nodded, glancing at Rand.

"ɪt woʊnt wɝk, nɑt ðɪs taɪm," ɹænd sɛd. "ə wɔɹ hɪɹ wəd teɪk tu mɛni ɹisɔɹsɪz. jə spoʊk ə ðɪs ɪɾɝɑldi - hiz hoʊldɪŋ ɔf ðə sintʃæn wɪð vɝtʃuəli noʊ səplaɪz ən fju mɛn. wəd juv əs ɛnɡeɪdʒ ə mæn ðət ɹisɔɹsfəl?"

"It won't work, not this time," Rand said. "A war here would take too many resources. You spoke of this Ituralde - he's holding off the Seanchan with virtually no supplies and few men. Would you have us engage a man that resourceful?"

haʊ θɔtfəl bæʃɪɹ simd, əz ɪf i wɝ ɪndid kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɛnɡeɪdʒɪŋ ðɪs ɪɾɝɑldi. mɛn!

How thoughtful Bashere seemed, as if he were indeed considering engaging this Ituralde. Men!

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðə seɪm. ɔfɝ əm ə tʃælənʒ, ən ðeɪd bi kjʊɹiəs, noʊ mæɾɝ ðət ðə tʃælənʒ wəd laɪkli ɛnd wɪð əm spɪɾɪd ɑn ə læns.

They were all the same. Offer them a challenge, and they'd be curious, no matter that the challenge would likely end with them spitted on a lance.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ fju mɛn əlaɪv laɪk ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi," bæʃɪɹ sɛd. "hi wəd bi ə ɡɹeɪt hɛlp tə əɹ kɑz, fəɹ sɝɾən. aɪv ɔlweɪz wʌndɝɾ ɪf aɪ kəd bit hɪm."

"There are few men alive like Rodel Ituralde," Bashere said. "He would be a great help to our cause, for certain. I've always wondered if I could beat him."

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛɾ əɡɛn, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə mæp. fɹəm wʌt nɪneɪiv kəd si, ɪt ʃoʊd tʃɹup kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃənz, mɑɹkt wɪð ənəteɪʃənz. ði il wɝ ən ɔɹɡənaɪz mɛs ə tʃɑɹkoʊl mɑɹks əkɹɔs ðə tɑp ʌv ɑɹæd dumən; ɪɾɝɑldiz fɔɹsɪz wɝ dip ɪndə ɑlməθ pleɪn, faɪɾɪŋ sintʃæn. ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɑɹæd dumən wɑz ə si ʌv keɪɑɾɪk blæk ənəteɪʃənz, laɪkli ðə pɝsənəl fɔɹsɪz ə vɛɹiəs noʊbəlz.

"No," Rand said again, looking over the map. From what Nynaeve could see, it showed troop concentrations, marked with annotations. The Aiel were an organized mess of charcoal marks across the top of Arad Doman; Ituralde's forces were deep into Almoth Plain, fighting Seanchan. The middle of Arad Doman was a sea of chaotic black annotations, likely the personal forces of various nobles.

"ɹəɑɹk, beɪl," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ wɑn jə tə siz ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns."

"Rhuarc, Bael," Rand said. "I want you to seize the members of the Council of Merchants."

ðə tɛnt wɑz saɪlənt.

The tent was silent.

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən ðəɾ ɪz waɪz, bɔɪ?" kædzueɪn faɪnəli æskt.

"Are you certain that is wise, boy?" Cadsuane finally asked.

"ðeɪɹ ɪn deɪnʒɝ fɹəm ðə fɔɹseɪkən," ɹænd sɛd, aɪdli tæpɪŋ ðə mæp wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "ɪf ɡɹeɪndəl ɹɪli hæz teɪkən ælsələm, ðən ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪm bæk wɪl də əs noʊ ɡʊd. hɪl bi soʊ fɑɹ bɪniθ əɹ kəmpʌlʃən ðət hɪl bɛɹli hæv ðə maɪn ʌv ə tʃaɪld. ʃiz nɑt sʌɾəl; ʃi nɛvɝ əz bɪn. wi nid ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns tə tʃuz ə nu kɪŋ. ðæts ði oʊnli weɪ tə bɹɪŋ ðɪs kɪŋdəm pis ən ɔɹɾɝ."

"They're in danger from the Forsaken," Rand said, idly tapping the map with his fingers. "If Graendal really has taken Alsalam, then getting him back will do us no good. He'll be so far beneath her Compulsion that he'll barely have the mind of a child. She's not subtle; she never has been. We need the Council of Merchants to choose a new king. That's the only way to bring this kingdom peace and order."

bæʃɪɹ nɑɾəd. "ɪts boʊld."

Bashere nodded. "It's bold."

"wi ɑɹ nɑt kɪdnæpɝz," beɪl sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"We are not kidnappers," Bael said, frowning.

"ju ɑɹ wʌɾ aɪ seɪ jə ɑɹ, beɪl," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli.

"You are what I say you are, Bael," Rand said quietly.

"wi ɑɹ stɪl fɹi pipəl, ɹænd ælθɹ," ɹəɑɹk sɛd.

"We are still free people, Rand al'Thor," Rhuarc said.

"aɪ wɪl tʃeɪnʒ ði il wɪð maɪ pæsɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd wɪð ə ʃeɪk ə hɪz hɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəl bi wʌns ðɪs ɪz ɔl θɹu, bʌt jə kænɑt ɹɪmeɪn wʌt jə wɝ. əl əv jə teɪk ʌp ðɪs tæsk. ʌv ɔl ðoʊz u fɑloʊ mi, aɪ tʃɹʌs jə ðə moʊst. ɪf wɝ gɑnə teɪk ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə kaʊnsəl wɪθaʊt θɹoʊɪŋ ðɪs læn fɝðɝ ɪndə wɔɹ, əl nid jəɹ kʌnɪŋ ən stɛlθ. jə kən pɹaʊl ɪndə ðɛɹ pæləsəz ən mænɝz əz jə ɪnfɪltʃɹeɪɾɪd ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ."

"I will change the Aiel with my passing," Rand said with a shake of his head. "I don't know what you'll be once this is all through, but you cannot remain what you were. I will have you take up this task. Of all those who follow me, I trust you the most. If we're going to take the members of the Council without throwing this land further into war, I will need your cunning and stealth. You can prowl into their palaces and manors as you infiltrated the Stone of Tear."

ɹəɑɹk ən beɪl ɹəɡɑɹɾəd wʌn ənʌðɝ, ʃɛɹɪŋ ə fɹaʊn.

Rhuarc and Bael regarded one another, sharing a frown.

"wʌns jə teɪk ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns," ɹænd kəntɪnjud, əpɛɹənli ʌnkənsɝn əbaʊt ðɛɹ wɝiz, "muv ði il ɪndə ðə sɪɾiz wɛɹ ðoʊz mɝtʃəns ɹuld. meɪk ʃʊɹ ðoʊz sɪɾiz doʊn dɪdʒɛnɝət. ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ əz jə dɪɾ ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən. fɹəm ðɛɹ, bɪɡɪn hʌntɪŋ bændəts ən ɛnfɔɹsɪŋ ðə lɔ. səplaɪz wɪl sun ɝaɪv fɹəm ðə si foʊk. teɪk sɪɾiz ɑn ðə koʊs fɝst, ðən muv ɪnlænd.

"Once you take the Council of Merchants," Rand continued, apparently unconcerned about their worries, "move the Aiel into the cities where those merchants ruled. Make sure those cities don't degenerate. Restore order as you did in Bandar Eban. From there, begin hunting bandits and enforcing the law. Supplies will soon arrive from the Sea Folk. Take cities on the coast first, then move inland.

wɪðɪn ə mʌnθs taɪm, ðə dəmɑni ʃəd bi floʊɪŋ təwɔɹd ju, ɹæðɝ ðən ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ju.

Within a month's time, the Domani should be flowing toward you, rather than running away from you.

ɔfɝ əm seɪfti ən fud, ən ɔɹɾɝ wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ʌv ɪtsɛlf."

Offer them safety and food, and order will take care of itself."

ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli ɹæʃənəl plæn. ɹænd ɹɪli dɪɾ əv ə klɛvɝ maɪnd, fəɹ ə mæn. ðəɹ wɑz ə lɑɾ ʌv ɡʊɾ ɪn hɪm, pɝhæps ðə vɛɹi soʊl ʌv ə liɾɝ, ɪf i kəd kip ɪz tɛmpɝ ɪn tʃɛk.

A surprisingly rational plan. Rand really did have a clever mind, for a man. There was a lot of good in him, perhaps the very soul of a leader, if he could keep his temper in check.

ɹəɑɹk kəntɪnjud tə ɹʌb ɪz tʃɪn. "ɪt wəd hɛlp ɪf wi hæd səm ə jəɹ sɑldəiənz, dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ. wɛtləndɝz də nɑt laɪk fɑloʊɪŋ il. ɪf ðeɪ kən pɹitɛn ðət wɛtləndɝz ɑɹ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, ðən ðəl bi mɔɹ laɪkli tə kʌm tə ʌs."

Rhuarc continued to rub his chin. "It would help if we had some of your Saldaeans, Davram Bashere. Wetlanders do not like following Aiel. If they can pretend that wetlanders are in charge, then they will be more likely to come to us."

bæʃɪɹ læft. "wil ɔlsoʊ meɪk naɪs tɑɹɡəts. əz sun əz wi siz ə fju mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl, ðə ɹɛst wɪl sɛn əsæsənz æftɝ əs fəɹ sɝɾən!"

Bashere laughed. "We'll also make nice targets. As soon as we seize a few members of the merchant council, the rest will send assassins after us for certain!"

ɹəɑɹk læft əz ɪf i θɔt ðəɾ ə ɡɹæn dʒoʊk. ði il sɛns ə hjumɝ wɑz ɪts oʊn sɔɹɾ ʌv ɑɾəti. "wi wɪl kip jə əlaɪv, dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ. ɪf wi də nɑt, wɪl stʌf jə ən sɛt jə ɑn ðət hɔɹs ə jʊɹz, ən jəl meɪk ə ɡɹæn kwɪvɝ fəɹ ðɛɹ æɹoʊz!"

Rhuarc laughed as if he thought that a grand joke. The Aiel sense of humor was its own sort of oddity. "We will keep you alive, Davram Bashere. If we do not, we will stuff you and set you on that horse of yours, and you will make a grand quiver for their arrows!"

beɪl læf laʊdli ət ðɪs, ən ðə meɪɾənz baɪ ðə dɔɹz bɪɡæn ənʌðɝ ɹaʊn ə hæntɔk.

Bael laughed loudly at this, and the Maidens by the doors began another round of handtalk.

bæʃɪɹ tʃʌkəld, ðoʊ hi dɪdn sim tə ʌndɝstæn ðə hjumɝ iðɝ. "ju ʃʊɹ ðɪs ɪz wʌt jə wɑnə du?" hi æskt ɹænd.

Bashere chuckled, though he didn't seem to understand the humor either. "You sure this is what you want to do?" he asked Rand.

ɹænd nɑɾəd. "dɪvaɪd səm ə jəɹ fɔɹsɪz, sɛn əm wɪð il ɡɹups əz ɹəɑɹk dɪsaɪdz."

Rand nodded. "Divide some of your forces, send them with Aiel groups as Rhuarc decides."

"ænd wʌɾ ʌv ɪɾɝɑldi?" bæʃɪɹ æskt, lʊkɪŋ bæk ət ðə mæp. "ðɛɹ woʊn bi pis fəɹ lɔŋ wʌns i ɹiəlaɪzɪz wiv ɪnveɪɾəd ɪz hoʊmlænd."

"And what of Ituralde?" Bashere asked, looking back at the map. "There won't be peace for long once he realizes we've invaded his homeland."

ɹænd tæp ðə mæp sɔfli fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "aɪ wɪl dil wɪð ɪm pɝsənəli," hi faɪnəli sɛd.

Rand tapped the map softly for a moment. "I will deal with him personally," he finally said.

tʃæptɝ eɪt

CHAPTER 8

klin ʃɝts ə dɑkmæstɝz skaɪ, ɪt wɑz kɔld. ðoʊz ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz, blɑɾɪŋ aʊt ðə sʌn, tɛmpɹəmɛntəl ən sʌlən. pɝhæps ði ʌðɝz - hɪɹ ɪn ðə kæmp dʒʌst aʊtsaɪɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn - hædnt noʊɾəst ðə pɝsɪstən klaʊdz, bʌt sɪuən hæd. noʊ seɪlɝ wəd mɪs ðɛm. nɑt dɑɹk ɪnʌf tə pɹɑməs ə stɔɹm, nɑt laɪɾ ɪnʌf tə ɪmplaɪ smuð wɔɾɝz iðɝ.

Clean Shirts A dockmaster's sky, it was called. Those gray clouds, blotting out the sun, temperamental and sullen. Perhaps the others - here in the camp just outside of Tar Valon - hadn't noticed the persistent clouds, but Siuan had. No sailor would miss them. Not dark enough to promise a storm, not light enough to imply smooth waters either.

ə skaɪ laɪk ðət wɑz æmbɪɡjuəs. jə kəd sɛɾ aʊɾ ən nɛvɝ si ə dʒɹɑp ə ɹeɪn əɹ ə hɪn ə stɔɹmwaɪnz. ɔɹ, wɪð bɛɹli ə moʊməns noʊɾəs, jə kəd faɪn jɝsɛlf ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə skwɔl. ɪt wɑz dəsitfəl, ðət blæŋkəɾ ə klaʊdz.

A sky like that was ambiguous. You could set out and never see a drop of rain or a hint of stormwinds. Or, with barely a moment's notice, you could find yourself in the middle of a squall. It was deceitful, that blanket of clouds.

moʊs pɔɹts tʃɑɹdʒd ə deɪli fi tə itʃ vɛsəl mʊɹɾ ɪn ðɛɹ hɑɹbɝz, bʌɾ ɑn deɪz ə stɔɹm -  wən noʊ fɪʃɝ kəd meɪk ə kætʃ - ðə fi wəd bi hævd, əɹ spɛɹɾ ɪntaɪɝli. ɑn ə deɪ laɪk ðɪs, haʊɛvɝ, wən ðəɹ wɝ ɡlumi klaʊdz bʌt noʊ pɹuf ə stɔɹmz, ðə dɑkmæstɝz wəd tʃɑɹdʒ ə fʊl deɪz ɹɛnt. ən soʊ ðə fɪʃɝ hæd tə meɪk ə tʃɔɪs. steɪ ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ ən weɪt, əɹ ɡoʊ fɪʃɪŋ tə ɹɪkup ðə dɑk fiz. moʊs deɪz laɪk ðɪs dɪdn tɝn stɔɹmi. moʊs deɪz laɪk ðɪs wɝ seɪf.

Most ports charged a daily fee to each vessel moored in their harbors, but on days of storm -  when no fisher could make a catch - the fee would be halved, or spared entirely. On a day like this, however, when there were gloomy clouds but no proof of storms, the dockmasters would charge a full day's rent. And so the fisher had to make a choice. Stay in the harbor and wait, or go fishing to recoup the dock fees. Most days like this didn't turn stormy. Most days like this were safe.

bʌɾ ɪf ə stɔɹm dɪd kʌm ɑn ə deɪ laɪk ðɪs, ɪt tɛndəd tə bi vɛɹi bæd. mɛni ʌv ðə moʊs tɛɹəbəl tɛmpɛsts ɪn hɪstɝi hæd spɹʌŋ fɹəm ə dɑkmæstɝz skaɪ. ðæts waɪ səm fɪʃɝz hæɾ ənʌðɝ neɪm fəɹ klaʊdz laɪk ðoʊz. ðeɪ kɔld əm ə laɪənfɪʃəz veɪl. ən ɪt hæd bɪn deɪz sɪns ðə skaɪ hæɾ ɔfɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ dɪfɹənt. sɪuən ʃɪvɝd, pʊlɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl kloʊs. ɪt wɑz ə bæd saɪn.

But if a storm did come on a day like this, it tended to be very bad. Many of the most terrible tempests in history had sprung from a dockmaster's sky. That's why some fishers had another name for clouds like those. They called them a lionfish's veil. And it had been days since the sky had offered anything different. Siuan shivered, pulling her shawl close. It was a bad sign.

ʃi daʊɾɪd mɛni fɪʃɝz hæd tʃoʊzən tə ɡoʊ aʊt ðɪs deɪ.

She doubted many fishers had chosen to go out this day.

"sɪuən?" ləleɪn æskt, vɔɪs tɪŋd wɪð ənɔɪəns. "du hɝi ʌp. ən aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ ɛni mɔɹ supɝstɪʃəs nɑnsɛns əbaʊt ðə skaɪ. ɑnəsli." ðə tɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ tɝn əweɪ ən kəntɪnjuɾ əlɔŋ ðə wɔk.

"Siuan?" Lelaine asked, voice tinged with annoyance. "Do hurry up. And I don't want to hear any more superstitious nonsense about the sky. Honestly." The tall Aes Sedai turned away and continued along the walk.

supɝstɪʃəs? sɪuən θɔɾ ɪndɪɡnənli. ə θaʊzən dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz ʌv wɪzdəm ɪzən supɝstɪʃən.

Superstitious? Siuan thought indignantly. A thousand generations of wisdom isn't superstition.

ɪts ɡʊd sɛns! bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, ən hɝiɾ æftɝ ləleɪn. ɝaʊn hɝ, ðə kæmp ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ lɔɪəl tə ɛɡwin kəntɪnjuɾ ɪts deɪli æktɪvəɾiz, əz stɛɾi əz ə klɑks ɡɪɹz. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz wʌn θɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɡʊɾ æt, ɪt wɑz kɹieɪɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ. tɛns wɝ ɝeɪnʒd ɪn klʌstɝz, baɪ ədʒɑ, əz ɪf tə ɪməteɪt ðə waɪt taʊɝz leɪaʊt. ðəɹ wɝ fju mɛn, ən moʊst ə ðoʊz u pæst - soʊlʒɝz ɑn ɛɹənz fɹəm ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪnz ɑɹmiz, ɡɹumz kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ hɔɹsəz - wɝ kwɪk tə bi əbaʊt ðɛɹ duɾiz. ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ aʊtnʌmbɝd baɪ wɝkɝ wɪmən, mɛni ʌv hum hæd ɡɔn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə ɪmbɹɔɪɾɝ ðə pæɾɝn ə ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɑn ðɛɹ skɝts əɹ bɑɾɪsɪz.

It's good sense! But she said nothing, and hurried after Lelaine. Around her, the camp of Aes Sedai loyal to Egwene continued its daily activities, as steady as a clock's gears. If there was one thing Aes Sedai were good at, it was creating order. Tents were arranged in clusters, by Ajah, as if to imitate the White Tower's layout. There were few men, and most of those who passed - soldiers on errands from Gareth Bryne's armies, grooms caring for horses - were quick to be about their duties. They were far outnumbered by worker women, many of whom had gone so far as to embroider the pattern of the Flame of Tar Valon on their skirts or bodices.

wʌn ə ði oʊnli ɑɾətiz əbaʊt ðə vɪlədʒ - ɪf wʌn ɪɡnɔɹd ðə fæk ðət ðəɹ wɝ tɛns ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹumz ən wʊɾən wɔkweɪz ɪnstɛɾ ə taɪl hɔlweɪz - wɑz ðə nʌmbɝ ə nɑvəsɪz. ðəɹ wɝ hʌnʒɹədz ən hʌnʒɹədz. ɪn fækt, ðə nʌmbɝ hæd tə bi oʊvɝ ə θaʊzənd naʊ, mɛni mɔɹ ðən ðə taʊɝ hæd hɛld ɪn ɹisən mɛmɹi. wʌns ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɹiunaɪɾɪd, nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz ðət hædn bɪn juzd ɪn dɛkeɪdz wəɾ əv tə bi ɹioʊpənd. ðeɪ maɪɾ ivən nid ðə sɛkən kɪtʃən.

One of the only oddities about the village - if one ignored the fact that there were tents instead of rooms and wooden walkways instead of tiled hallways - was the number of novices. There were hundreds and hundreds. In fact, the number had to be over a thousand now, many more than the Tower had held in recent memory. Once the Aes Sedai were reunited, novices' quarters that hadn't been used in decades would have to be reopened. They might even need the second kitchen.

ðiz nɑvəsɪz bʌsəld ɝaʊn ɪn fæmliz, ən moʊst ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛm. səm dɪd ðɪs aʊɾ ə hæbət; hu peɪɾ ətɛnʃən tə nɑvəsɪz? bʌɾ ʌðɝz dɪd soʊ aʊɾ ə dɪsplɛʒɝ. baɪ ðɛɹ ɛstəmeɪʃən, wɪmən eɪdʒd ɪnʌf tə bi mʌðɝz ən ɡɹændmʌðɝz - ɪndid, mɛni hu wɝ mʌðɝz ən ɡɹændmʌðɝz - ʃʊdn əv bɪn ɛntɝɾ ɪndə ðə nɑvəs bʊk. bʌt wʌt kəd bi dʌn?

These novices bustled around in families, and most of the Aes Sedai tried to ignore them. Some did this out of habit; who paid attention to novices? But others did so out of displeasure. By their estimation, women aged enough to be mothers and grandmothers - indeed, many who were mothers and grandmothers - shouldn't have been entered into the novice book. But what could be done?

ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, hæd dɪklɛɹd ðəɾ ɪt ʃəd hæpən.

Egwene al'Vere, the Amyrlin Seat, had declared that it should happen.

sɪuən kəd stɪl sɛns ʃɑk ɪn səm ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃi pæst. ɛɡwin wɑz tə hæv bɪn kɛɹfəli kəntʃɹoʊld. wʌt hæd ɡɔn ɹɔŋ? wən hæd ði æmɪɝlɪn ɡɑɾən əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm? sɪuən wʊɾə teɪkən mɔɹ smʌɡ dɪlaɪt fɹəm ðoʊz lʊks ɪf ʃi hædn hɝsɛlf wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɡwinz kəntɪnjud kæptɪvəɾi ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðət wɑz ə laɪənfɪʃəz veɪl ɪndid. pətɛnʃəl fəɹ ɡɹeɪt səksɛs, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ fəɹ ɡɹeɪt dɪzæstɝ. ʃi hɝiɾ æftɝ ləleɪn.

Siuan could still sense shock in some of the Aes Sedai she passed. Egwene was to have been carefully controlled. What had gone wrong? When had the Amyrlin gotten away from them? Siuan would have taken more smug delight from those looks if she hadn't herself worried about Egwene's continued captivity in the White Tower. That was a lionfish's veil indeed. Potential for great success, but also for great disaster. She hurried after Lelaine.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə stæɾəs ə ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz?" ləleɪn æskt, nɑt bɑðɝɪŋ tə lʊk ət sɪuən.

"What is the status of the negotiations?" Lelaine asked, not bothering to look at Siuan.

jə kəd ɡoʊ tə wʌn ə ðə sɛʃənz jɝsɛlf ən faɪn aʊt, sɪuən θɔt. bʌt ləleɪn wɑntəd tə bi sin supɝvaɪzɪŋ, nɑt teɪkɪŋ ən æktɪv hænd. ən æskɪŋ sɪuən, ɪn ði oʊpən, wɑz ɔlsoʊ ə kælkjəleɪɾəd muv. sɪuən wɑz noʊn əz wʌn ʌv ɛɡwinz kɑnfədæns ən stɪl kæɹid səm mɛʒɝ ə noʊɾɝaɪəti fəɹ hævɪŋ bɪn æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf. ðə θɪŋz sɪuən sɛd tə ləleɪn wɝn ɪmpɔɹɾənt; biɪŋ sin seɪɪŋ ðɛm, haʊɛvɝ, ɪnkɹis ðə wʊmənz ɪnfluəns ɪn kæmp.

You could go to one of the sessions yourself and find out, Siuan thought. But Lelaine wanted to be seen supervising, not taking an active hand. And asking Siuan, in the open, was also a calculated move. Siuan was known as one of Egwene's confidants and still carried some measure of notoriety for having been Amyrlin herself. The things Siuan said to Lelaine weren't important; being seen saying them, however, increased the woman's influence in camp.

"ðeɪ doʊnt ɡoʊ wɛl, ləleɪn," sɪuən sɛd. "ɪleɪɾəz ɛməsɛɹiz nɛvɝ pɹɑməs ɛniθɪŋ, ən sim ɪndɪɡnən ɛni taɪm wi ɹeɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt tɑpɪks, laɪk ɹiɪnsteɪɾɪŋ ðə blu ədʒɑ. aɪ daʊt ðeɪv ɛni ɹil əθɔɹəɾi fɹəm ɪleɪɾə tə meɪk baɪndɪŋ əɡɹiməns."

"They don't go well, Lelaine," Siuan said. "Elaida's emissaries never promise anything, and seem indignant any time we raise important topics, like reinstating the Blue Ajah. I doubt they have any real authority from Elaida to make binding agreements."

"m," ləleɪn sɛd θɔtfəli, nɑɾɪŋ tə ə ɡɹup ə nɑvəsɪz. ðeɪ bɑbd ɪndə kɝtsiz. ɪn ə ʃɹud dɪsɪʒən, ləleɪn hæd bɪɡʌn tɔkɪŋ vɛɹi æksɛptɪŋli ʌv ðə nu nɑvəsɪz.

"Hmm," Lelaine said thoughtfully, nodding to a group of novices. They bobbed into curtsies. In a shrewd decision, Lelaine had begun talking very acceptingly of the new novices.

ɹoʊmændəz dɪslaɪk ə ðɛm wɑz wɛl noʊn; naʊ ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ɡɔn, ɹoʊmændə hæd bɪɡʌn tə ɪmplaɪ ðət wʌns ɹɛkənsɪlieɪʃən wɑz ətʃivd, ðɪs "fulɪʃnəs" wɪð ði eɪdʒɪd nɑvəsɪz wəɾ əv tə bi dɛlt wɪð swɪfli. haʊɛvɝ, mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ə ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wɝ siɪŋ ɛɡwinz wɪzdəm.

Romanda's dislike of them was well known; now that Egwene was gone, Romanda had begun to imply that once reconciliation was achieved, this "foolishness" with the aged novices would have to be dealt with swiftly. However, more and more of the other sisters were seeing Egwene's wisdom.

ðəɹ wɑz ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ əmʌŋ ðə nu nɑvəsɪz, ən nɑɾ ə fju wəd bi ɹeɪz tə æksɛptɪd ðə moʊmən ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz ətʃivd. ɹisənli - baɪ ɔfɝɪŋ tæsɪɾ æksɛptəns ə ðiz wɪmən -  ləleɪn hæd ɡɪvən hɝsɛlf jɛɾ ənʌðɝ taɪ tə ɛɡwin.

There was great strength among the new novices, and not a few would be raised to Accepted the moment the White Tower was achieved. Recently - by offering tacit acceptance of these women -  Lelaine had given herself yet another tie to Egwene.

sɪuən aɪd ðə ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ fæmli ʌv nɑvəsɪz. ðeɪ hæd kɝtsid tə ləleɪn ɔlmoʊst əz kwɪkli ən əz dɪfɝɛntʃəli əz ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɪt wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ klɪɹ ðæt, æftɝ mʌnθs əɾ ə steɪlmeɪt, ləleɪn wɑz wɪnɪŋ ðə bæɾəl əɡɛnst ɹoʊmændə fəɹ supɪɹiɔɹɪɾi.

Siuan eyed the retreating family of novices. They had curtsied to Lelaine almost as quickly and as deferentially as they would have to the Amyrlin. It was becoming clear that, after months at a stalemate, Lelaine was winning the battle against Romanda for superiority.

ən ðət wɑz ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ pɹɑbləm.

And that was a very large problem.

sɪuən dɪdn dɪslaɪk ləleɪn. ʃi wɑz keɪpəbəl, stʃɹɔŋ-wɪld ən dɪsaɪsɪv. ðeɪ hæd bɪn fɹɛnz wʌns, ðoʊ ðɛɹ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp hæd tʃeɪnʒd dʒɹæstɪkli wɪð sɪuənz tʃeɪnʒd pəzɪʃən.

Siuan didn't dislike Lelaine. She was capable, strong-willed and decisive. They had been friends once, though their relationship had changed drastically with Siuan's changed position.

jɛs, ʃi maɪt seɪ ʃi laɪk ləleɪn. bʌt ʃi dɪdn tʃɹʌs ðə wʊmən, ən ʃi pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli dɪdnt wɑnə si hɝ əz æmɪɝlɪn. ɪn ənʌðɝ ɛɹə, ləleɪn wʊɾə dʌn wɛl ɪn ðə pəzɪʃən. bʌt ðɪs wɝl niɾəd ɛɡwin, ən - fɹɛndʃɪp əɹ nɑt - sɪuən kʊdn əfɔɹd tə lɛt ðɪs wʊmən dɪspleɪs ðə ɹaɪtfəl æmɪɝlɪn. ən ʃi hæd tə meɪk sɝɾən ləleɪn wɑzn teɪkɪŋ ækʃən tə pɹɪvɛn ɛɡwinz ɹɪtɝn.

Yes, she might say she liked Lelaine. But she didn't trust the woman, and she particularly didn't want to see her as Amyrlin. In another era, Lelaine would have done well in the position. But this world needed Egwene, and - friendship or not - Siuan couldn't afford to let this woman displace the rightful Amyrlin. And she had to make certain Lelaine wasn't taking action to prevent Egwene's return.

"wɛl," ləleɪn sɛd, "wi ʃæl əv tə dɪskʌs ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz ɪn ðə hɔl. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑns əm tə kəntɪnju, soʊ wi sɝɾənli kæn lɛɾ əm stɑp. jɛt ðəɹ mʌs bi ə weɪ tə meɪk əm ɪfɛktɪv.

"Well," Lelaine said, "we shall have to discuss the negotiations in the Hall. The Amyrlin wants them to continue, so we certainly can't let them stop. Yet there must be a way to make them effective.

ði æmɪɝlɪnz dɪzaɪɝz mʌs bi sin tə, wʊdn jə seɪ?"

The Amyrlin's desires must be seen to, wouldn't you say?"

"əndaʊɾɪdli," sɪuən ɹɪplaɪd flætli.

"Undoubtedly," Siuan replied flatly.

ləleɪn aɪd hɝ, ən sɪuən kɝs hɝsɛlf fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz ʃoʊ. ləleɪn niɾəd tə bɪliv ðət sɪuən wɑz ɑn əɹ saɪd. "aɪm sɑɹi, ləleɪn. ðət wʊmən əz mi ɪn ə fjʊɹi. waɪ dʌz ɪleɪɾə hoʊl tɔks ɪf ʃi woʊn kənsiɾ ə sɪŋɡəl pɔɪnt?"

Lelaine eyed her, and Siuan cursed herself for letting her emotions show. Lelaine needed to believe that Siuan was on her side. "I'm sorry, Lelaine. That woman has me in a fury. Why does Elaida hold talks if she won't concede a single point?"

ləleɪn nɑɾəd. "jɛs. bʌɾ u kən seɪ waɪ ɪleɪɾə dʌz wʌt ʃi dʌz? ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɹɪpɔɹts ɪndəkeɪt ðəɾ ɪleɪɾəz liɾɝʃɪp ə ðə taʊɝ əz bɪn . . . ɪɹæɾɪk ət bɛst."

Lelaine nodded. "Yes. But who can say why Elaida does what she does? The Amyrlin's reports indicate that Elaida's leadership of the Tower has been . . . erratic at best."

sɪuən sɪmpli nɑɾəd. fɔɹtʃənətli, ləleɪn dɪdn sim tə səspɛk sɪuənz dɪslɔɪəlti. əɹ ʃi dɪdn kɛɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt. ɪt wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl haʊ ɪnɑkjuəs ðə wɪmən θɔt sɪuən wɑz, naʊ ðəɾ əɹ paʊɝ hæd bɪn soʊ ɡɹeɪtli ɹədust.

Siuan simply nodded. Fortunately, Lelaine didn't seem to suspect Siuan's disloyalty. Or she didn't care about it. It was remarkable how innocuous the women thought Siuan was, now that her power had been so greatly reduced.

biɪŋ wik wɑz ə nu ɪkspɪɹiəns. fɹəm əɹ vɛɹi ɝli deɪz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, sɪstɝz hæd noʊɾəd əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ən əɹ ʃɑɹpnəs ə maɪnd. wɪspɝz ə hɝ bɪkʌmɪŋ æmɪɝlɪn hæd bɪɡʌn ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli - ət taɪmz, ɪt sim ðət ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf hæd pʊʃt sɪuən dɝɛkli ɪndə ðə sit.

Being weak was a new experience. From her very early days in the White Tower, sisters had noted her strength and her sharpness of mind. Whispers of her becoming Amyrlin had begun almost immediately - at times, it seemed that the Pattern itself had pushed Siuan directly into the Seat.

ðoʊ hɝ heɪsti əsɛn tə æmɪɝlɪn waɪl soʊ jʌŋ hæd kʌm əz ə sɝpɹaɪz tə mɛni, ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd nɑt bɪn ʃɑkt. wən jə fɪʃt wɪð skwɪɾ əz beɪt, jə ʃʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪz tə kætʃ fæŋfɪʃ. ɪf jə wɑntəd tə kætʃ ilz, jə juz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɪntaɪɝli.

Though her hasty ascent to Amyrlin while so young had come as a surprise to many, she herself had not been shocked. When you fished with squid as bait, you shouldn't be surprised to catch fangfish. If you wanted to catch eels, you used something else entirely.

wən ʃid fɝs bɪn hild, hɝ ɹədus paʊɝ hæd bɪn ə dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. bʌt ðət wɑz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. jɛs, ɪt wɑz ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ tə bi bɪniθ soʊ mɛni, tə læk ɹɪspɛk fɹəm ðoʊz ɝaʊn hɝ.

When she'd first been Healed, her reduced power had been a disappointment. But that was changing. Yes, it was infuriating to be beneath so many, to lack respect from those around her.

haʊɛvɝ, kəz ʃi wɑz wikɝ ɪn paʊɝ, mɛni sim tə əsum ʃi wɑz wikɝ ɪn pəlɪɾəkəl skɪl əz wɛl! kəd pipəl ɹɪli fɝɡɛt soʊ kwɪkli? ʃi wɑz faɪndɪŋ əɹ nu stæɾəs əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə bi lɪbɝeɪɾɪŋ.

However, because she was weaker in power, many seemed to assume she was weaker in political skill as well! Could people really forget so quickly? She was finding her new status among the Aes Sedai to be liberating.

"jɛs," ləleɪn sɛɾ əz ʃi nɑɾəd tə ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ə nɑvəsɪz, "aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ ɪts taɪm tə sɛn ɛnvɔɪz tə ðə kɪŋdəmz ðəɾ ælθɹ hæzən kɑŋkɝd. wi meɪ nɑt hoʊl ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz noʊ ɹizən tə əbændən əɹ pəlɪɾəkəl stuɝdʃɪp ə ðə wɝld."

"Yes," Lelaine said as she nodded to another group of novices, "I believe that it is time to send envoys to the kingdoms that al'Thor hasn't conquered. We may not hold the White Tower itself, but that is no reason to abandon our political stewardship of the world."

"jɛs, ləleɪn," sɪuən sɛd. "bʌɾ ɑɹ jə sɝɾən ðət ɹoʊmændə woʊn ɑɹɡju əɡɛns ðæt?"

"Yes, Lelaine," Siuan said. "But are you certain that Romanda won't argue against that?"

"waɪ wəd ʃi?" ləleɪn sɛd dɪsmɪsɪvli. "ɪt wʊdn meɪk sɛns."

"Why would she?" Lelaine said dismissively. "It wouldn't make sense."

"lɪɾəl ɹoʊmændə dʌz meɪks sɛns," sɪuən sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ʃi dɪsəɡɹiz dʒʌs tə spaɪt ju. bʌɾ aɪ dɪd si hɝ tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð mɛɹələndə ɝliɝ ɪn ðə wik."

"Little Romanda does makes sense," Siuan said. "I think she disagrees just to spite you. But I did see her chatting with Maralenda earlier in the week."

ləleɪn fɹaʊnd. mɛɹələndə wɑz ə dɪstən kʌzən tə ðə tʃɹəkən laɪn.

Lelaine frowned. Maralenda was a distant cousin to the Trakand line.

sɪuən kʌvɝɾ ə smaɪl. ɪt wɑz əmeɪzɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ jə kəɾ əkɑmplɪʃ wən pipəl dɪsmɪs ju. haʊ mɛni wɪmən hæd ʃi dɪsmɪs kəz ðeɪ læk vɪzəbəl paʊɝ? haʊ ɔfən hæd ʃi bɪn mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd mʌtʃ əz ʃi naʊ mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd ləleɪn?

Siuan covered a smile. It was amazing how much you could accomplish when people dismissed you. How many women had she dismissed because they lacked visible power? How often had she been manipulated much as she now manipulated Lelaine?

"aɪ ʃæl lʊk ɪndə ɪt," ləleɪn sɛd. ɪt dɪdn mæɾɝ wʌt ʃi dɪskʌvɝd; əz lɔŋ əz ʃi wɑz kɛp bɪzi wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ɹoʊmændə, ʃi wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə spɛn əz mʌtʃ taɪm stilɪŋ paʊɝ fɹəm ɛɡwin.

"I shall look into it," Lelaine said. It didn't matter what she discovered; as long as she was kept busy worrying about Romanda, she wouldn't be able to spend as much time stealing power from Egwene.

ɛɡwin. ði æmɪɝlɪn niɾəd tə hɝi ʌp ən fɪnɪʃ wɪð əɹ plɑɾɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. wʌt ɡʊd wəɾ ɪt də tə ʌndɝmaɪn ɪleɪɾə ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊtsaɪd kɹʌmbəld waɪl ɛɡwin wɑznt wɑtʃɪŋ? sɪuən kəɾ oʊnli kip ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn dɪstʃɹæktəd fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli naʊ ðət ləleɪn hɛl sətʃ ə dɪstɪŋkt ædvæntɪdʒ. laɪt! səm deɪz, ʃi fɛl ðət ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒʌɡəl bʌɾɝd lɪv sɪlvɝpaɪk.

Egwene. The Amyrlin needed to hurry up and finish with her plotting in the White Tower. What good would it do to undermine Elaida if the Aes Sedai outside crumbled while Egwene wasn't watching? Siuan could only keep Romanda and Lelaine distracted for so long, particularly now that Lelaine held such a distinct advantage. Light! Some days, she felt that she was trying to juggle buttered live silverpike.

sɪuən tʃɛk ðə pəzɪʃən ə ðə sʌn bɪhaɪn ðət dɑkmæstɝz skaɪ. ɪt wɑz leɪɾ æftɝnun. "fɪʃ ɡʌts," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "aɪl nid tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ, ləleɪn."

Siuan checked the position of the sun behind that dockmaster's sky. It was late afternoon. "Fish guts," she muttered. "I'll need to be going, Lelaine."

ləleɪn ɡlænst ət hɝ. "ju hæv wɑʃɪŋ, aɪ pɹɪzum? fəɹ ðət ɹʌfaɪən ʌv ə dʒɛnɝəl ə jʊɹz?"

Lelaine glanced at her. "You have washing, I presume? For that ruffian of a general of yours?"

"hiz nɑɾ ə ɹʌfaɪən," sɪuən snæpt, ðən kɝs hɝsɛlf. ʃid luz mʌtʃ ə hɝ ædvæntɪdʒ ɪf ʃi kɛp snæpɪŋ ət ðoʊz u θɔt ðɛmsɛlvz əɹ bɛɾɝz.

"He's not a ruffian," Siuan snapped, then cursed herself. She'd lose much of her advantage if she kept snapping at those who thought themselves her betters.

ləleɪn smaɪld, aɪz twɪŋkəlɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi nu sʌmθɪŋ spɛʃəl. ɪnsʌfɝəbəl wʊmən. fɹɛn əɹ nɑt, sɪuən hæd hæf ə maɪn tə waɪp . . .

Lelaine smiled, eyes twinkling as if she knew something special. Insufferable woman. Friend or not, Siuan had half a mind to wipe . . .

noʊ. "aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz, ləleɪn," sɪuən fɔɹst aʊt. "aɪ ɡɛɾ ɑn ɛdʒ, θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv wʌt ðət mæn dɪmænz ə mi."

No. "I apologize, Lelaine," Siuan forced out. "I get on edge, thinking of what that man demands of me."

"jɛs," ləleɪn sɛd, daʊntɝnɪŋ əɹ lɪps. "aɪv kənsɪɾɝd ɑn ðɪs, sɪuən. ði æmɪɝlɪn meɪ hæv sʌfɝd bɹaɪnz bʊliɪŋ ʌv ə sɪstɝ, bʌɾ aɪ woʊn stæn fəɹ ɪt. jəɹ wʌn ə maɪ ətɛndəns naʊ."

"Yes," Lelaine said, downturning her lips. "I've considered on this, Siuan. The Amyrlin may have suffered Bryne's bullying of a sister, but I won't stand for it. You're one of my attendants now."

wʌn ə jəɹ ətɛndəns? sɪuən θɔt. aɪ θɔt ðəɾ aɪ wɑz dʒʌst səpoʊz tə səpɔɹt jə əntɪl ɛɡwin ɹɪtɝnd.

One of your attendants? Siuan thought. I thought that I was just supposed to support you until Egwene returned.

"jɛs," ləleɪn mjuzd, "aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk ɪts taɪm tə pʊɾ ən ɛn tə jəɹ sɝvətud tə bɹaɪn. aɪ ʃæl peɪ ɔf jəɹ dɛt, sɪuən."

"Yes," Lelaine mused, "I should think it's time to put an end to your servitude to Bryne. I shall pay off your debt, Siuan."

"peɪ ɔf maɪ dɛt?" sɪuən sɛd, filɪŋ ə moʊmən ə pænɪk. "ɪz ðət waɪz? nɑt ðəɾ aɪ wʊdn maɪn biɪŋ fɹi ʌv ðət mæn, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt maɪ pəzɪʃən ɔfɝz mi kwaɪt jusfəl ɑpɝtunəɾiz fəɹ lɪsnɪŋ ɪn ɑn ɪz plænz."

"Pay off my debt?" Siuan said, feeling a moment of panic. "Is that wise? Not that I wouldn't mind being free of that man, of course, but my position offers me quite useful opportunities for listening in on his plans."

"plænz?" ləleɪn æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"Plans?" Lelaine asked, frowning.

sɪuən kɹɪnʒd ɪnwɝdli. ðə læs θɪŋ ʃi wɑntəd wɑz tə ɪmplaɪ ɹɔŋduɪŋ ɑn bɹaɪnz pɑɹt.

Siuan cringed inwardly. The last thing she wanted was to imply wrongdoing on Bryne's part.

laɪt, ðə mæn wɑz stʃɹɪkt ɪnʌf tə meɪk wɔɹɾɝz lʊk slɑpi ɪn kipɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊðz.

Light, the man was strict enough to make Warders look sloppy in keeping their oaths.

ʃi ʃəd dʒʌs lɛt ləleɪn ɛn ðɪs fulɪʃ sɝvətud, bʌt ðə θɔt meɪɾ əɹ stʌmək tʃɝn.

She should just let Lelaine end this foolish servitude, but the thought made her stomach churn.

bɹaɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsəpɔɪntɪd ðət ʃid bɹoʊkən əɹ oʊθ tə hɪm mʌnθs bɪfɔɹ. wɛl, ʃi hædn bɹoʊkən ðəɾ oʊθ - ʃid dʒʌs poʊstpoʊn əɹ pɪɹiəɾ ə sɝvəs. bʌt tʃɹaɪ kənvɪnsɪŋ ðə stʌbɝn ful ə ðət fækt!

Bryne was already disappointed that she'd broken her oath to him months before. Well, she hadn't broken that oath - she'd just postponed her period of service. But try convincing the stubborn fool of that fact!

ɪf ʃi tʊk ði izi weɪ aʊt naʊ, wʌt wəɾ i θɪŋk ə hɝ? hid θɪŋk ðət hid wʌn, ðət ʃid pɹuvən hɝsɛlf əneɪbəl tə kip əɹ wɝd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ ʃid lɛt ðət hæpən.

If she took the easy way out now, what would he think of her? He'd think that he'd won, that she'd proven herself unable to keep her word. There was no way she'd let that happen.

bɪsaɪdz, ʃi wɑzn əbaʊt tə lɛt ləleɪn bi ðə wʌn u fɹid hɝ. ðət wəd dʒʌs muv əɹ dɛt fɹəm bɹaɪn tə ləleɪn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd kəlɛkt ɪɾ ɪn fɑɹ mɔɹ sʌɾəl weɪz, bʌɾ itʃ kɔɪn wəɾ ɛn ʌp biɪŋ peɪd wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ɪf oʊnli θɹu dɪmænz ə lɔɪəlti.

Besides, she wasn't about to let Lelaine be the one who freed her. That would just move her debt from Bryne to Lelaine. The Aes Sedai would collect it in far more subtle ways, but each coin would end up being paid one way or another, if only through demands of loyalty.

"ləleɪn," sɪuən sɛd sɔfli, "aɪ doʊn səspɛk ðə ɡʊd dʒɛnɝəl ʌv ɛniθɪŋ. haʊɛvɝ, hi kəntʃɹoʊlz əɹ ɑɹmiz. kən i ɹɪli bi tʃɹʌstɪd tə də əz ɹikwaɪɝd wɪθaʊɾ ɛni supɝvɪʒən?"

"Lelaine," Siuan said softly, "I don't suspect the good general of anything. However, he controls our armies. Can he really be trusted to do as required without any supervision?"

ləleɪn snɪft. "aɪm nɑt sɝɾən ɛni mæn kən bi tʃɹʌstɪd wɪθaʊt dɝɛkʃən."

Lelaine sniffed. "I'm not certain any man can be trusted without direction."

"aɪ heɪt duɪŋ ɪz lɔnʒɹi," sɪuən sɛd. wɛl, ʃi dɪd. ivən ɪf ʃi wʊdn bi stɑp fɹəm duɪŋ ɪt fəɹ ɔl ə ðə ɡoʊld ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. "bʌɾ ɪf ðə duɾi kips mi kloʊs, wɪð ə lɪsnɪŋ ɪɹ. . . ."

"I hate doing his laundry," Siuan said. Well, she did. Even if she wouldn't be stopped from doing it for all of the gold in Tar Valon. "But if the duty keeps me close, with a listening ear. . . ."

"jɛs," ləleɪn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ sloʊli. "jɛs, aɪ si ðət jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt. əl nɑt fɝɡɛt jəɹ sækɹəfaɪs, sɪuən. vɛɹi wɛl, jə ɑɹ dɪsmɪst."

"Yes," Lelaine said, nodding slowly. "Yes, I see that you are right. I will not forget your sacrifice, Siuan. Very well, you are dismissed."

ləleɪn tɝnd, ɡlænsɪŋ daʊn əɾ əɹ hænd, əz ɪf lɔŋɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ. pɹɑbli wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə deɪ wən - əz æmɪɝlɪn - ʃi kəɾ ɔfɝ əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ fəɹ ə kɪs wən ʃi pɑɹɾəd weɪz wɪð ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ. laɪt, bʌɾ ɛɡwin niɾəd tə ɹɪtɝn sun. bʌɾɝd sɪlvɝpaɪk! bʌɾɝd, fleɪmɪŋ sɪlvɝpaɪk!

Lelaine turned, glancing down at her hand, as if longing for something. Probably wishing for the day when - as Amyrlin - she could offer her Great Serpent ring for a kiss when she parted ways with another sister. Light, but Egwene needed to return soon. Buttered silverpike! Buttered, flaming silverpike!

sɪuən meɪɾ əɹ weɪ təwɔɹd ði ɛdʒ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp. bɹaɪnz ɑɹmi sɝaʊndəd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɪŋ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪŋ fɹəm bɹaɪn. ɪt wəd teɪk ə ɡʊd hæf-aʊɝ tə wɔk tə hɪz kəmæn poʊst. fɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi faʊn ə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ u wɑz teɪkɪŋ ə loʊɾ ə səplaɪz, bɹɔt θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ, tə ði ɑɹmi. ðə ʃɔɹt, ɡɹɪzəl mæn ɪmiɾiətli əɡɹid tə lɛɾ əɹ ɹaɪd wɪð ðə tɝnəps, ðoʊ hi dɪd sim pʌzəld waɪ ʃi dɪdnt ɡoʊ ɡɛɾ ə hɔɹs, əz bɪfɪɾɪd ən ɛɛs sədaɪz steɪʃən. wɛl, ɪt wɑzn ðət fɑɹ, ən ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð vɛdʒtəbəlz wɑz ə feɪt fɑɹ lɛs əndɪɡnɪfaɪd ðən biɪŋ fɔɹs tə dʒaʊns ɝaʊn ɑn ðə bæk ʌv ə hɔɹs. ɪf ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn wɑntəd tə kəmpleɪn əbaʊɾ əɹ tɑɹɾinəs, ðən hid ɡɛɾ ən ɪɹfəl, hi wʊd!

Siuan made her way toward the edge of the Aes Sedai camp. Bryne's army surrounded the Aes Sedai camp in a large ring, but she was on the far side of the ring from Bryne. It would take a good half-hour to walk to his command post. Fortunately, she found a wagon driver who was taking a load of supplies, brought through a gateway, to the army. The short, grizzled man immediately agreed to let her ride with the turnips, though he did seem puzzled why she didn't go get a horse, as befitted an Aes Sedai's station. Well, it wasn't that far, and riding with vegetables was a fate far less undignified than being forced to jounce around on the back of a horse. If Gareth Bryne wanted to complain about her tardiness, then he'd get an earful, he would!

ʃi sɛɾəld bæk əɡɛnst ə lʌmpi sæk ə tɝnəps, bɹaʊn-skɝɾɪd lɛɡz hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə bæk ə ðə wæɡən. əz ðə kɑɹt ɹoʊld ʌp ə slaɪɾ ɪnklaɪn, ʃi kəd si oʊvɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp - wɪð ɪts waɪt tɛns ən sɪɾəlaɪk ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən. ɹɪŋd ɝaʊn ɪt wɑz ði ɑɹmi, wɪð smɔlɝ tɛns ɪn nit stʃɹeɪt laɪnz, ən ɹɪŋd ɝaʊn əm wɑz ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɹɪŋ ə kæmp fɑloʊɝz.

She settled back against a lumpy sack of turnips, brown-skirted legs hanging over the back of the wagon. As the cart rolled up a slight incline, she could see over the Aes Sedai camp - with its white tents and citylike organization. Ringed around it was the army, with smaller tents in neat straight lines, and ringed around them was a growing ring of camp followers.

bɪɑn ɪɾ ɔl, ðə lændskeɪp wɑz bɹaʊn, ðə wɪntɝ snoʊz mɛltəd, bʌt spɹɪŋ spɹaʊts skɛɹs. ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd wɑz pɑkəɾɪd wɪð θɪkəts ə skɹʌb oʊk; ʃædoʊz ɪn væliz ən twɪstɪŋ laɪnz ə tʃɪmni smoʊk pɔɪntəd tə dɪstən vɪlədʒəz. ɪt wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ haʊ fəmɪljɝ, haʊ wɛlkəm, ðiz ɡɹæslænz fɛlt. wən ʃi hæd fɝs kʌm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ʃid bɪn ʃʊɹ ʃid nɛvɝ kʌm tə lʌv ðɪs lændlɑkt kʌntʃɹisaɪd.

Beyond it all, the landscape was brown, the winter snows melted, but spring sprouts scarce. The countryside was pocketed with thickets of scrub oak; shadows in valleys and twisting lines of chimney smoke pointed to distant villages. It was surprising how familiar, how welcome, these grasslands felt. When she had first come to the White Tower, she'd been sure she'd never come to love this landlocked countryside.

naʊ ʃi hæd lɪv mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə hɝ laɪf ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn ðən ʃi hæɾ ɪn tɛɹ. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəlt ət taɪmz tə ɹikɔl ðət ɡɝl u hæd soʊn nɛts ən ɡɔn ɑn ɝli-mɔɹnɪŋ tʃɹɔlɪŋ tʃɹɪps wɪð əɹ fɑðɝ.

Now she had lived much more of her life in Tar Valon than she had in Tear. It was difficult at times to recall that girl who had sewn nets and gone on early-morning trawling trips with her father.

ʃid bɪkʌm sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ə wʊmən u tʃɹeɪɾɪd ɪn sikɹəts ɹæðɝ ðən fɪʃ.

She'd become something else, a woman who traded in secrets rather than fish.

sikɹəts, ðoʊz paʊɝfəl, dɑməneɪɾɪŋ sikɹəts. ðeɪ hæd bɪkʌm əɹ laɪf. noʊ lʌv seɪv fəɹ juθfəl dælaɪənsɪz. noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɛntæŋɡəlməns, əɹ mʌtʃ ɹum fəɹ fɹɛndʃɪps. ʃid foʊkəst ɑn oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ: faɪndɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hɛlpɪŋ hɪm, ɡaɪɾɪŋ hɪm, hoʊpfəli kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ hɪm.

Secrets, those powerful, dominating secrets. They had become her life. No love save for youthful dalliances. No time for entanglements, or much room for friendships. She'd focused on only one thing: finding the Dragon Reborn. Helping him, guiding him, hopefully controlling him.

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd daɪd fɑloʊɪŋ ðət seɪm kwɛst, bʌɾ ət list ʃi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡoʊ aʊɾ ən si ðə wɝld. sɪuən hæd ɡɹoʊn oʊld - ɪn spɪɹət, ɪf nɑɾ ɪn bɑɾi - kupt ʌp ɪn ðə taʊɝ, pʊlɪŋ əɹ stʃɹɪŋz ən nʌdʒɪŋ ðə wɝld. ʃid dʌn səm ɡʊd. taɪm wəd tɛl ɪf ðoʊz ɛfɝts hæd bɪn ɪnʌf.

Moiraine had died following that same quest, but at least she had been able to go out and see the world. Siuan had grown old - in spirit, if not in body - cooped up in the Tower, pulling her strings and nudging the world. She'd done some good. Time would tell if those efforts had been enough.

ʃi dɪdn ɹəɡɹɛɾ əɹ laɪf. jɛt, ət ðɪs moʊmənt, pæsɪŋ ɑɹmi tɛns - hoʊlz ən bɹoʊkən ɹʌts ɪn ðə pæθ ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə kɑɹt, meɪkɪŋ ɪt ɹæɾəl laɪk dʒɹaɪd fɪʃboʊnz ɪn ə kɛɾəl - ʃi ɛnvid mɔɪɹeɪn. haʊ ɔfən hæd sɪuən bɑðɝd tə lʊk aʊɾ ə hɝ wɪndoʊ təwɔɹd ðə bjuɾəfəl ɡɹin lændskeɪp, bɪfɔɹ ɪɾ ɔl hæd stɑɹɾəd ɡoʊɪŋ sɪkli? ʃi ən mɔɪɹeɪn hæd fɔt soʊ hɑɹd tə seɪv ðɪs wɝld, bʌt ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðɛmsɛlvz wɪθaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə ɛndʒɔɪ ɪn ɪt.

She didn't regret her life. Yet, at this moment, passing army tents - holes and broken ruts in the path shaking the cart, making it rattle like dried fishbones in a kettle - she envied Moiraine. How often had Siuan bothered to look out of her window toward the beautiful green landscape, before it all had started going sickly? She and Moiraine had fought so hard to save this world, but they had left themselves without anything to enjoy in it.

pɝhæps sɪuən hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk ɪn steɪɪŋ wɪð ðə blu, ənlaɪk lin, hu hæd teɪkən ði ɑpɝtunəɾi ɪn ðɛɹ stɪlɪŋ ən hilɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ tə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. noʊ, sɪuən θɔt, wæɡən ɹætlɪŋ, smɛlɪŋ ə bɪɾɝ tɝnəps. noʊ, aɪm stɪl foʊkəst ɑn seɪvɪŋ ðɪs blæstəd wɝld. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ swɪtʃɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹin fəɹ hɝ. ðoʊ, θɪŋkɪŋ ə bɹaɪn, ʃi dɪd wɪʃ ðət ðə blu wɝ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ laɪk ðə ɡɹin ɪn sɝɾən weɪz.

Perhaps Siuan had made a mistake in staying with the Blue, unlike Leane, who had taken the opportunity in their stilling and Healing to change to the Green Ajah. No, Siuan thought, wagon rattling, smelling of bitter turnips. No, I'm still focused on saving this blasted world. There would be no switching to the Green for her. Though, thinking of Bryne, she did wish that the Blue were a little more like the Green in certain ways.

sɪuən ði æmɪɝlɪn hædn hæɾ ɛni taɪm fəɹ ɛntæŋɡəlməns, bʌt wʌɾ ə sɪuən ði ətɛndənt? ɡaɪɾɪŋ pipəl wɪð kwaɪət mənɪpjəleɪʃənz ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə lɑt mɔɹ skɪl ðən bʊliɪŋ əm wɪð ðə paʊɝ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ɪt wɑz pɹuvɪŋ mɔɹ fʊlfɪlɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ lɛft əɹ wɪθaʊt ðə kɹʌʃɪŋ weɪɾ ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ʃid fɛl dʊɹɪŋ əɹ jɪɹz liɾɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. wɑz ðɛɹ, pɝhæps, ɹum ɪn əɹ laɪf fəɹ ə fju mɔɹ tʃeɪnʒəz?

Siuan the Amyrlin hadn't had any time for entanglements, but what of Siuan the attendant? Guiding people with quiet manipulations required a lot more skill than bullying them with the power of the Amyrlin Seat, and it was proving more fulfilling. But it also left her without the crushing weight of responsibility she'd felt during her years leading the White Tower. Was there, perhaps, room in her life for a few more changes?

ðə wæɡən ɹitʃt ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ði ɑɹmi kæmp, ən ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əɾ əɹ oʊn fulɪʃnəs əz ʃi hɑp daʊn, ðən nɑɾəd əɹ θæŋks tə ðə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ. wɑz ʃi ə ɡɝl, bɛɹli oʊld ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ fɝs fʊl-deɪ blækfɪʃ tʃɹɔl? ðəɹ wɑz noʊ jus ɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ə bɹaɪn ðət weɪ. ət lis nɑt ɹaɪt naʊ. ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ tə du.

The wagon reached the far side of the army camp, and she shook her head at her own foolishness as she hopped down, then nodded her thanks to the wagon driver. Was she a girl, barely old enough for her first full-day blackfish trawl? There was no use in thinking of Bryne that way. At least not right now. There was too much to do.

ʃi wɔkt əlɔŋ ðə pɝɪməɾɝ ə ðə kæmp, ɑɹmi tɛns tə hɝ lɛft. ɪt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹk, ən læntɝnz bɝnɪŋ pɹɛʃəs ɔɪl ɪluməneɪɾəd dɪsɔɹɡənaɪzd ʃæntiz ən tɛns tə hɝ ɹaɪt. əhɛɾ ə hɝ, ə smɔl sɝkjəlɝ pælɪsɑd ɹoʊz ɑn ði ɑɹmi saɪd. ɪt dɪdn ɪnkloʊz ði ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi - ɪn fækt, ɪt wɑz oʊnli bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ sɛvɹəl dʌzən ɔfəsɝ tɛns ən səm lɑɹdʒɝ kəmæn tɛns. ɪt wɑz tə ækt əz ə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən ɪn ən ɪmɝdʒənsi, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz əz ə sɛntɝ ʌv ɑpɝeɪʃənz - bɹaɪn fɛlt ɪt ɡʊd tə hæv ə fɪzɪkəl bæɹiɝ sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ kæmp fɹəm ðə pleɪs wɛɹ i hɛl kɑnfɝəns wɪð ɪz ɔfəsɝz.

She walked along the perimeter of the camp, army tents to her left. It was growing dark, and lanterns burning precious oil illuminated disorganized shanties and tents to her right. Ahead of her, a small circular palisade rose on the army side. It didn't enclose the entire army - in fact, it was only big enough for several dozen officer tents and some larger command tents. It was to act as a fortification in an emergency, but always as a center of operations - Bryne felt it good to have a physical barrier separating the larger camp from the place where he held conference with his officers.

wɪð ðə kənfjuʒən ə ðə səvɪljən kæmp, ən wɪð sətʃ ə lɔŋ bɔɹɾɝ tə pətʃɹoʊl, ɪt wəd bi tu izi fəɹ spaɪz tə əpɹoʊtʃ ɪz tɛns ʌðɝwaɪz.

With the confusion of the civilian camp, and with such a long border to patrol, it would be too easy for spies to approach his tents otherwise.

ðə pælɪsɑd wɑz oʊnli əbaʊt θɹi-kɔɹɾɝz dʌn, bʌt wɝk wɑz pɹəɡɹɛsɪŋ kwɪkli. pɝhæps i wəd tʃuz tə sɝaʊn ði ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɪf ðə sidʒ kəntɪnjud lɔŋ ɪnʌf. fəɹ naʊ, bɹaɪn fɛl ðət ðə smɔl, fɔɹɾəfaɪd kəmæn poʊst wəd nɑɾ oʊnli sədʒɛst sɪkjʊɹəɾi tə ðə soʊlʒɝz, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ lɛn əm ə sɛns ʌv əθɔɹəɾi.

The palisade was only about three-quarters done, but work was progressing quickly. Perhaps he would choose to surround the entire army, eventually, if the siege continued long enough. For now, Bryne felt that the small, fortified command post would not only suggest security to the soldiers, but also lend them a sense of authority.

ði eɪt-fʊt wʊɾən steɪks ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊn əhɛd, ə laɪn ə sɛntənəlz stændɪŋ saɪd baɪ saɪd, pɔɪns ɹeɪz tə ðə skaɪ. waɪl hoʊldɪŋ ə sidʒ wʌn dʒɛnɝəli hæɾ ə lɑɾ ə mænpaʊɝ fəɹ wɝk laɪk ðɪs. ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə pælɪsɑd ɡeɪt nu tə lɛɾ əɹ pæs, ən ʃi kwɪkli meɪɾ əɹ weɪ tə bɹaɪnz tɛnt. ʃi dɪɾ əv wɑʃɪŋ tə du, bʌt moʊst ʌv ɪt wəd pɹɑbli hæv tə weɪɾ əntɪl ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ʃi wɑz səpoʊz tə miɾ ɛɡwin ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ əz sun əz ɪt ɡɹu dɑɹk, ən ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə sʌnsɛt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə feɪd.

The eight-foot wooden stakes rose from the ground ahead, a line of sentinels standing side by side, points raised to the sky. While holding a siege one generally had a lot of manpower for work like this. The guards at the palisade gate knew to let her pass, and she quickly made her way to Bryne's tent. She did have washing to do, but most of it would probably have to wait until the morning. She was supposed to meet Egwene in Tel'aran'rhiod as soon as it grew dark, and the glow of the sunset was already beginning to fade.

bɹaɪnz tɛnt, əz juʒəwəl, ʃoʊn wɪð oʊnli ə vɛɹi feɪn laɪt. waɪl pipəl aʊtsaɪd skwɑndɝd ðɛɹ ɔɪl, hi skɹɪmpt. moʊst ə hɪz mɛn lɪv bɛɾɝ ðən i dɪd. ful mæn. sɪuən pʊʃt əɹ weɪ ɪndə ðə tɛnt wɪθaʊt kɔlɪŋ. ɪf i wɑz fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə tʃeɪnʒ wɪθaʊt ɡoʊɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə skɹin, ðən i wɑz fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə bi sin duɪŋ ɪt.

Bryne's tent, as usual, shone with only a very faint light. While people outside squandered their oil, he scrimped. Most of his men lived better than he did. Fool man. Siuan pushed her way into the tent without calling. If he was foolish enough to change without going behind the screen, then he was foolish enough to be seen doing it.

hi wɑz siɾəd əɾ ɪz dɛsk wɝkɪŋ baɪ ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə sɑlətɛɹi kændəl. hi əpɪɹd tə bi ɹiɾɪŋ skaʊt ɹɪpɔɹts.

He was seated at his desk working by the light of a solitary candle. He appeared to be reading scout reports.

sɪuən snɪft, lɛɾɪŋ ðə tɛn flæps dʒɹup kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɝ. nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl læmp! ðət mæn! "ju wɪl ɹuən jəɹ aɪz ɹɛɾɪŋ baɪ sətʃ pʊɹ laɪt, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn."

Siuan sniffed, letting the tent flaps droop closed behind her. Not a single lamp! That man! "You will ruin your eyes reading by such poor light, Gareth Bryne."

"aɪ hæv ɹɛd baɪ ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl kændəl fəɹ moʊst ə maɪ laɪf, sɪuən," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ oʊvɝ ə peɪdʒ ən nɑt lʊkɪŋ ʌp. "æn əl əv jə noʊ ðət maɪ aɪsaɪɾ ɪz ðə seɪm əz ɪt wɑz wən aɪ wɑz ə bɔɪ."

"I have read by the light of a single candle for most of my life, Siuan," he said, turning over a page and not looking up. "And I'll have you know that my eyesight is the same as it was when I was a boy."

"oʊ?" sɪuən sɛd. "soʊ jəɹ seɪɪŋ ðət jəɹ aɪsaɪt wɑz pʊɹ tə bɪɡɪn wɪð?"

"Oh?" Siuan said. "So you're saying that your eyesight was poor to begin with?"
