bɹaɪn ɡɹɪnd, bʌt kəntɪnjuɾ ɪz ɹiɾɪŋ. sɪuən snɪft əɡɛn, laʊdli, tə meɪk ʃʊɹ i hɝd. ðən ʃi woʊv ə ɡloʊb ə laɪɾ ən sɛn ɪt hʌvɝɪŋ oʊvɝ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz dɛsk. ful mæn. ʃi wʊdn əv ɪm ɡoʊɪŋ soʊ blaɪn i fɛl ɪn bæɾəl tə ən ətæk i dɪdn si. æftɝ sɛɾɪŋ ðə laɪt bɪsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd -  pɝhæps tu kloʊs fəɹ ɪm tə bi kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð ɪt wɪθaʊt skuɾɪŋ oʊvɝ - ʃi wɔkt oʊvɝ tə plʌk kloʊðɪŋ ɔf ðə dʒɹaɪɪŋ laɪn ʃid stʃɹʌŋ əkɹɔs ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə tɛnt. hid vɔɪs noʊ kəmpleɪn əbaʊɾ əɹ juzɪŋ ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪz tɛn fəɹ dʒɹaɪɪŋ lɔnʒɹi, ən hædn teɪkən ɪt daʊn. ðət wɑz ə dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. ʃid bɪn æntɪsəpeɪɾɪŋ tʃæstaɪzɪŋ ɪm fəɹ ðæt.

Bryne grinned, but continued his reading. Siuan sniffed again, loudly, to make sure he heard. Then she wove a globe of light and sent it hovering over beside his desk. Fool man. She wouldn't have him going so blind he fell in battle to an attack he didn't see. After setting the light beside his head -  perhaps too close for him to be comfortable with it without scooting over - she walked over to pluck clothing off the drying line she'd strung across the center of the tent. He'd voiced no complaint about her using the inside of his tent for drying laundry, and hadn't taken it down. That was a disappointment. She'd been anticipating chastising him for that.

"ə wʊmən fɹəm ðə kæmp aʊtsaɪɾ əpɹoʊtʃt mi tədeɪ," bɹaɪn sɛd, ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz tʃɛɹ tə ðə saɪd, ðən pɪkɪŋ ʌp ənʌðɝ stæk ə peɪdʒəz. "ʃi ɔfɝd mi lɔnʒɹi sɝvəs. ʃiz ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ ə ɡɹup ʌv wɑʃwɪmən ɪn ðə kæmp, ən ʃi kleɪm ðət ʃi kəd də maɪ wɑʃ mɔɹ kwɪkli ən ɪfɛktɪvli ðən ə sɪŋɡəl dɪstʃɹæktəd meɪdsɝvən kʊd."

"A woman from the camp outside approached me today," Bryne said, shifting his chair to the side, then picking up another stack of pages. "She offered me laundry service. She's organizing a group of washwomen in the camp, and she claimed that she could do my wash more quickly and effectively than a single distracted maidservant could."

sɪuən fɹoʊz, spɛɹɪŋ ə ɡlæns ət bɹaɪn, hu wɑz lʊkɪŋ θɹu hɪz peɪpɝz. hɪz stʃɹɔŋ dʒɔ wɑz lɪɾ ɑn ðə lɛf baɪ ði ivən waɪt laɪɾ ə hɝ ɡloʊb ən ɑn ðə ɹaɪt baɪ ðə flɪkɝɪŋ ɔɹənʒ kændəllaɪt.

Siuan froze, sparing a glance at Bryne, who was looking through his papers. His strong jaw was lit on the left by the even white light of her globe and on the right by the flickering orange candlelight.

səm mɛn wɝ meɪd wik baɪ eɪdʒ, ʌðɝz wɝ meɪd tə lʊk taɪɝɾ əɹ slʌvənli. bɹaɪn hæd sɪmpli bɪkʌm dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt, laɪk ə pɪlɝ, kɹæftɪd baɪ ə mæstɝ stoʊnmeɪsən, ðən lɛf tə ði ɛləməns. eɪdʒ hædn ɹədus bɹaɪnz ɪfɛktɪvnəs əɹ ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ. ɪt hæd sɪmpli ɡɪvən ɪm kɛɹɪktɝ, dʌstɪŋ ɪz tɛmpəlz wɪð sɪlvɝ, kɹisɪŋ ɪz fɝm feɪs wɪð laɪnz ʌv wɪzdəm.

Some men were made weak by age, others were made to look tired or slovenly. Bryne had simply become distinguished, like a pillar, crafted by a master stonemason, then left to the elements. Age hadn't reduced Bryne's effectiveness or his strength. It had simply given him character, dusting his temples with silver, creasing his firm face with lines of wisdom.

"ænd wʌd jə tɛl ðɪs wʊmən?" ʃi æskt.

"And what did you tell this woman?" she asked.

bɹaɪn tɝn ə peɪdʒ oʊvɝ. "aɪ toʊld əɹ ðəɾ aɪ wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð maɪ lɔnʒɹi." hi lʊkt ʌp ət hɝ. "aɪ hæv tə seɪ, sɪuən, ðəɾ aɪm sɝpɹaɪzd. aɪ hæɾ əsum ðəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd noʊ lɪɾəl ʌv wɝk sətʃ əz ðɪs, bʌt ɹɛɹli hæv maɪ junəfɔɹmz noʊn sətʃ ə pɝfəkt kɑmbəneɪʃən ə stɪfnəs ən kʌmfɝt.

Bryne turned a page over. "I told her that I was satisfied with my laundry." He looked up at her. "I have to say, Siuan, that I'm surprised. I had assumed that an Aes Sedai would know little of work such as this, but rarely have my uniforms known such a perfect combination of stiffness and comfort.

jə ɑɹ tə bi kəmɛndɪd."

You are to be commended."

sɪuən tɝn əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, haɪɾɪŋ əɹ blʌʃ. ful mæn! ʃi hæd kɑz kɪŋz tə nil bɪfɔɹ hɝ! ʃi mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən plæn fəɹ ðə dɪlɪvɝəns ə mænkaɪn ɪtsɛlf! ən i kəmpləmɛntɪɾ əɹ ɑn əɹ lɔndɝɪŋ skɪlz?

Siuan turned away from him, hiding her blush. Fool man! She had caused kings to kneel before her! She manipulated the Aes Sedai and planned for the deliverance of mankind itself! And he complimented her on her laundering skills?

ðə θɪŋ wɑz, fɹəm bɹaɪn, ðət wɑz ən ɑnəst ən minɪŋfəl kɑmpləmənt. hi dɪdn lʊk daʊn ɑn wɑʃwɪmən, əɹ ɑn ɹʌnɝ bɔɪz. hi tʃɹiɾəd ɔl wɪð ɛkwəɾi. ə pɝsən dɪdnt ɡeɪn stætʃɝ ɪn ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪnz aɪz baɪ biɪŋ ə kɪŋ əɹ kwin; wʌn ɡeɪn stætʃɝ baɪ kipɪŋ tə wʌnz oʊðz ən duɪŋ wʌnz duɾi. tə hɪm, ə kɑmpləmən ɑn lɔnʒɹi wɛl dʌn wɑz əz minɪŋfəl əz ə mɛɾəl əwɔɹɾəd tə ə soʊlʒɝ u hæd stʊɾ ɪz ɡɹaʊn bɪfɔɹ ði ɛnəmi.

The thing was, from Bryne, that was an honest and meaningful compliment. He didn't look down on washwomen, or on runner boys. He treated all with equity. A person didn't gain stature in Gareth Bryne's eyes by being a king or queen; one gained stature by keeping to one's oaths and doing one's duty. To him, a compliment on laundry well done was as meaningful as a medal awarded to a soldier who had stood his ground before the enemy.

ʃi ɡlæns bæk ət hɪm. hi wɑz stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ. ful mæn! ʃi hɝidli tʊk daʊn ənʌðɝ ə hɪz ʃɝts ən bɪɡæn foʊldɪŋ ɪt.

She glanced back at him. He was still watching her. Fool man! She hurriedly took down another of his shirts and began folding it.

"ju nɛvɝ dɪɾ ɪkspleɪn tə maɪ sæɾəsfækʃən waɪ jə bɹoʊk jəɹ oʊθ," hi sɛd.

"You never did explain to my satisfaction why you broke your oath," he said.

sɪuən fɹoʊz, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə bæk wɔl ə ðə tɛnt, spleɪd wɪð ʃædoʊz ə ðə stɪl-hæŋɪŋ lɔnʒɹi. "aɪ θɔt ðət jə ʌndɝstʊd," ʃi sɛd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə foʊld. "aɪ hæɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn sɑlədɑɹ. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ kʊdn vɛɹi wɛl lɛt lɑɡən ɹʌn əbaʊt fɹi, naʊ kəɾ aɪ? aɪ hæd tə faɪn ɪm ən ɡɛɾ ɪm tə sɑlədɑɹ."

Siuan froze, looking at the back wall of the tent, splayed with shadows of the still-hanging laundry. "I thought that you understood," she said, continuing to fold. "I had important information for the Aes Sedai in Salidar. Besides, I couldn't very well let Logain run about free, now could I? I had to find him and get him to Salidar."

"ðoʊz ɑɹ ɪkskjusɪz," bɹaɪn sɛd. "oʊ, aɪ noʊ ðət ðəɹ tʃɹu. bʌt jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə kən saɪt fɔɹ fæks ən juz əm tə haɪd ðə ɹil tʃɹuθ əz ɪfɛktɪvli əz ənʌðɝ maɪt juz laɪz."

"Those are excuses," Bryne said. "Oh, I know that they're true. But you're Aes Sedai. You can cite four facts and use them to hide the real truth as effectively as another might use lies."

"soʊ jə kleɪm ɪm ə laɪɝ?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

"So you claim I'm a liar?" she demanded.

"noʊ," hi sɛd. "dʒʌst ən oʊθbɹeɪkɝ."

"No," he said. "Just an oathbreaker."

ʃi ɡlænst ət hɪm, aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ. waɪ, ʃid lɛɾ ɪm hɪɹ ðə ɹʌf saɪɾ ʌv. . . .

She glanced at him, eyes widening. Why, she'd let him hear the rough side of. . . .

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, beɪðd ɪn ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə tu laɪts, aɪz θɔtfəl.

She hesitated. He was watching her, bathed in the glow of the two lights, eyes thoughtful.

ɹɪzɝvd, bʌt nɑɾ əkjuzətɔɹi. "ðæt kwɛstʃən dʒɹoʊv mi hɪɹ, jə noʊ," hi sɛd. "ɪts waɪ aɪ hʌntəd jə ɔl ðət weɪ. ɪts waɪ aɪ faɪnəli swɔɹ tə ðiz ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ aɪ hæd lɪɾəl wɪʃ tə bi pʊld ɪndə jɛɾ ənʌðɝ wɔɹ ət tɑɹ vəlɑn. aɪ dɪɾ ɪɾ ɔl kəz aɪ niɾəd tə ʌndɝstænd. aɪ hæd tə noʊ.

Reserved, but not accusatory. "That question drove me here, you know," he said. "It's why I hunted you all that way. It's why I finally swore to these rebel Aes Sedai, though I had little wish to be pulled into yet another war at Tar Valon. I did it all because I needed to understand. I had to know.

waɪ? waɪ dɪd ðə wʊmən wɪð ðoʊz aɪz - ðoʊz pæʃənət, hɔntɪŋ aɪz - bɹeɪk əɹ oʊθ?"

Why? Why did the woman with those eyes - those passionate, haunting eyes - break her oath?"

"aɪ toʊl jə aɪ wɑz gɑnə ɹɪtɝn tə jə ən fʊlfɪl ðəɾ oʊθ," sɪuən sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɪm ən snæpɪŋ ə ʃɝɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ tə ənɹɪŋkəl ɪt.

"I told you I was going to return to you and fulfill that oath," Siuan said, turning away from him and snapping a shirt in front of her to unwrinkle it.

"ənʌðɝ ɪkskjus," hi sɛd sɔfli. "ənʌðɝ ænsɝ fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɪl aɪ ɛvɝ əv ðə fʊl tʃɹuθ fɹəm ju, sɪuən sɑntʃ? hæz ɛniwʌn ɛvɝ hæɾ ɪt?" hi saɪd, ən ʃi hɝd peɪpɝz ɹʌsəl, ðə kændəlz laɪt flɪkɝɪŋ ɪn ðə feɪn stɝ ə hɪz muvməns əz i tɝn bæk tə hɪz ɹɪpɔɹts.

"Another excuse," he said softly. "Another answer from an Aes Sedai. Will I ever have the full truth from you, Siuan Sanche? Has anyone ever had it?" He sighed, and she heard papers rustle, the candle's light flickering in the faint stir of his movements as he turned back to his reports.

"wɛn aɪ wɑz stɪl ən æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ," sɪuən sɛd sɔfli, "aɪ wɑz wʌn ə fɔɹ pipəl pɹɛzənt wən ə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ ənaʊns ði ɪmənən bɝθ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɑn ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt."

"When I was still an Accepted in the White Tower," Siuan said softly, "I was one of four people present when a Foretelling announced the imminent birth of the Dragon Reborn on the slopes of Dragonmount."

hɪz ɹʌslɪŋ fɹoʊz.

His rustling froze.

"wʌn ə ðə θɹi ʌðɝz pɹɛzənt," sɪuən kəntɪnjud, "daɪɾ ɑn ðə spɑt. ənʌðɝ daɪd sun æftɝ. aɪm kɑnfəɾənt ðət ʃi - ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɝsɛlf - wɑz mɝɾɝd baɪ ðə blæk ədʒɑ. jɛs, ɪɾ ɪɡzɪsts. ɪf jə tɛl ɛniwʌn ðəɾ aɪ ədmɪɾəd ðət fækt, əl əv jəɹ tʌŋ.

"One of the three others present," Siuan continued, "died on the spot. Another died soon after. I'm confident that she - the Amyrlin Seat herself - was murdered by the Black Ajah. Yes, it exists. If you tell anyone that I admitted that fact, I'll have your tongue.

"ɛniweɪ, bɪfɔɹ ʃi daɪd, ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊt hʌntɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən. wʌn baɪ wʌn, ðoʊz wɪmən vænɪʃt. ðə blæks mʌst əv tɔɹtʃɝd ðɛɹ neɪmz aʊɾ ə tæmɹə bɪfɔɹ kɪlɪŋ hɝ. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ɡɪvən ʌp ðoʊz neɪmz izəli. aɪ stɪl ʃɪvɝ, səmtaɪmz, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt wʌt ʃi mʌst əv ɡɔn θɹu.

"Anyway, before she died, the Amyrlin sent Aes Sedai out hunting the Dragon. One by one, those women vanished. The Blacks must have tortured their names out of Tamra before killing her. She would not have given up those names easily. I still shiver, sometimes, thinking about what she must have gone through.

"sun, ðəɹ wɝ dʒʌs ðə tu ʌv əs lɛft u nu. mɔɪɹeɪn ən mi. wi wɝn səpoʊz tə hɪɹ ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ. wi wɝ dʒʌst æksɛptɪd, ɪn ðə ɹum baɪ hæpənstæns. aɪ bɪliv ðət tæmɹə wɑz sʌmhaʊ eɪbəl tə wɪθhoʊld əɹ neɪmz fɹəm ðə blæks, fəɹ ɪf ʃi hædnt, wiɾ əv əndaʊɾɪdli bɪn mɝɾɝd laɪk ði ʌðɝz.

"Soon, there were just the two of us left who knew. Moiraine and me. We weren't supposed to hear the Foretelling. We were just Accepted, in the room by happenstance. I believe that Tamra was somehow able to withhold our names from the Blacks, for if she hadn't, we'd have undoubtedly been murdered like the others.

"ðæt lɛf tu ʌv ʌs. ði oʊnli tu ɪn ɔl ə ðə wɝld u nu wʌt wɑz kʌmɪŋ. ət list, ði oʊnli tu hu sɝv ðə laɪt. ən soʊ aɪ dɪd wʌɾ aɪ hæd tə, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. aɪ dɛɾəkeɪtəd maɪ laɪf tə pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡənz kʌmɪŋ. aɪ swɔɹ tə si əs θɹu ðə læs bæɾəl. tə də wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi -  wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi - tə bɛɹ ðə bɝɾən aɪ hæd bɪn ɡɪvən. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn ʌðɝ pɝsən aɪ nu aɪ kəd tʃɹʌst, ən ʃiz naʊ dɛd."

"That left two of us. The only two in all of the world who knew what was coming. At least, the only two who served the Light. And so I did what I had to, Gareth Bryne. I dedicated my life to preparing for the Dragon's coming. I swore to see us through the Last Battle. To do whatever was necessary -  whatever was necessary - to bear the burden I had been given. There was only one other person I knew I could trust, and she is now dead."

sɪuən tɝnd, miɾɪŋ ɪz aɪz əkɹɔs ðə tɛnt. ə bɹiz ɹɪpəl ðə wɔlz ən flʌɾɝd ðə kændəl, bʌt bɹaɪn sæt stɪl, wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ.

Siuan turned, meeting his eyes across the tent. A breeze rippled the walls and fluttered the candle, but Bryne sat still, watching her.

"soʊ jə si, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ hæd tə dɪleɪ fʊlfɪlɪŋ maɪ oʊθ tə jə kəz ʌv ʌðɝ oʊðz. aɪ swɔɹ tə si ðɪs θɹu tə ði ɛnd, ən ðə dʒɹæɡən əz nɑt jɛt mɛɾ ɪz dɛstəni ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ə pɝsənz oʊðz mʌs fɑloʊ ðɛɹ ɔɹɾɝ ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns. wən aɪ swɔɹ tə ju, aɪ dɪd nɑt pɹɑməs tə sɝv jə ɪmiɾiətli. aɪ wɑz ɪntɛnʃənəli kɛɹfəl ɑn ðət pɔɪnt. jəl kɔl ɪɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝdpleɪ. aɪ wəd kɔl ɪt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls."

"So you see, Gareth Bryne," she said. "I had to delay fulfilling my oath to you because of other oaths. I swore to see this through to the end, and the Dragon has not yet met his destiny at Shayol Ghul. A person's oaths must follow their order of importance. When I swore to you, I did not promise to serve you immediately. I was intentionally careful on that point. You will call it an Aes Sedai wordplay. I would call it something else."

"wɪtʃ ɪz?" hi æskt.

"Which is?" he asked.

"duɪŋ wʌt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə pɹətɛk ju, jəɹ lænz ən jəɹ pipəl, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. jə bleɪm mi fəɹ ðə lɔs ʌv ə bɑɹn ən səm kaʊz. wɛl, ðən aɪ sədʒɛs ðət jə kənsɪɾɝ ðə kɑs tə jəɹ pipəl ʃəd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn feɪl. səmtaɪmz, pɹaɪsəz mʌs bi peɪd soʊ ðəɾ ə mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt duɾi kən bi sɝvd. aɪ wəɾ ɪkspɛkt ə soʊlʒɝ tə ʌndɝstæn ðæt."

"Doing what was necessary to protect you, your lands and your people, Gareth Bryne. You blame me for the loss of a barn and some cows. Well, then I suggest that you consider the cost to your people should the Dragon Reborn fail. Sometimes, prices must be paid so that a more important duty can be served. I would expect a soldier to understand that."

"ju ʃʊɾə toʊl mi," hi sɛd, stɪl miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz. "ju ʃʊɾə ɪkspleɪn u jə wɝ."

"You should have told me," he said, still meeting her eyes. "You should have explained who you were."

"wʌt?" sɪuən æskt. "wʊd juv bɪliv mi?"

"What?" Siuan asked. "Would you have believed me?"

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

He hesitated.

"bɪsaɪdz," ʃi sɛd fɹæŋkli, "aɪ dɪdn tʃɹʌs ju. əɹ pɹiviəs miɾɪŋ hæd nɑt bɪn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli . . . æmɪkəbəl, əz aɪ ɹikɔl. kəɾ aɪ hæv teɪkən ðət ɹɪsk, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn, ɑn ə mæn aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ? kəɾ aɪ hæv ɡɪvən ɪm kəntʃɹoʊl oʊvɝ ðə sikɹəts aɪ əloʊn noʊ, sikɹəts ðət niɾəd tə bi pæst ɑn tə ðə nu æmɪɝlɪn sit? ʃəɾ aɪ hæv spɛɹɾ ivən ə moʊmənt wən ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ðə hæŋmənz nus?"

"Besides," she said frankly, "I didn't trust you. Our previous meeting had not been particularly . . . amicable, as I recall. Could I have taken that risk, Gareth Bryne, on a man I did not know? Could I have given him control over the secrets I alone know, secrets that needed to be passed on to the new Amyrlin Seat? Should I have spared even a moment when the entire world was wearing the hangman's noose?"

ʃi hɛl ðoʊz aɪz, dɪmændɪŋ ən ænsɝ.

She held those eyes, demanding an answer.

"noʊ," hi faɪnəli ədmɪɾəd. "bɝn mi, sɪuən, bʌt noʊ. jə ʃʊdn əv weɪɾəd. jə ʃʊdn əv meɪd ðəɾ oʊθ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs!"

"No," he finally admitted. "Burn me, Siuan, but no. You shouldn't have waited. You shouldn't have made that oath in the first place!"

"ju ʃʊɾə bɪn mɔɹ kɛɹfəl tə lɪsən," ʃi sɛd, faɪnəli bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪz ɡeɪz wɪð ə snɪf. "aɪ sədʒɛs ðəɾ ɪf jə swɛɹ sʌmwʌn ɪndə sɝvəs ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ, jə bi kɛɹfəl tə stɪpjəleɪɾ ə taɪm fɹeɪm fəɹ ðət sɝvəs."

"You should have been more careful to listen," she said, finally breaking his gaze with a sniff. "I suggest that if you swear someone into service in the future, you be careful to stipulate a time frame for that service."

bɹaɪn ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən sɪuən wɪp ðə faɪnəl ʃɝɾ ɔf ə ðə dʒɹaɪɪŋ laɪn, kɑzɪŋ ɪt tə ʃeɪk, meɪkɪŋ ə blɝi ʃædoʊ ɑn ðə bæk wɔl ə ðə tɛnt.

Bryne grunted and Siuan whipped the final shirt off of the drying line, causing it to shake, making a blurry shadow on the back wall of the tent.

"wɛl," bɹaɪn sɛd, "aɪ toʊl maɪsɛlf aɪɾ oʊnli hoʊl jə tə wɝk əz lɔŋ əz ɪt tʊk mi tə ɡɛt ðəɾ ænsɝ. naʊ aɪ noʊ. aɪ wəd seɪ ðət - "

"Well," Bryne said, "I told myself I'd only hold you to work as long as it took me to get that answer. Now I know. I would say that - "

"stɑp!" sɪuən snæpt, spɪnɪŋ ɑn ɪm ən pɔɪntɪŋ.

"Stop!" Siuan snapped, spinning on him and pointing.

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"doʊn seɪ ɪt," ʃi θɹɛɾənd. "aɪl ɡæɡ jə ən liv jə hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ əntɪl sʌndaʊn təmɑɹoʊ. doʊn θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪ woʊnt."

"Don't say it," she threatened. "I'll gag you and leave you hanging in the air until sundown tomorrow. Don't think that I won't."

bɹaɪn sæt, saɪlənt.

Bryne sat, silent.

"aɪm nɑt fɪnɪʃt wɪð jə jɛt, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn." ʃi wɪp ðə ʃɝɾ ɪn əɹ hænz, ðən foʊldəɾ ɪt.

"I'm not finished with you yet, Gareth Bryne." She whipped the shirt in her hands, then folded it.

"aɪ ʃæl tɛl jə wən aɪ æm."

"I shall tell you when I am."

"laɪt, wʊmən," hi mʌɾɝd, ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. "ɪf aɪd noʊn jə wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪfɔɹ tʃeɪsɪŋ jə tə sɑlədɑɹ . . . ɪf aɪd noʊn wʌɾ aɪ wɑz duɪŋ. . . ."

"Light, woman," he muttered, almost under his breath. "If I'd known you were Aes Sedai before chasing you to Salidar . . . if I'd known what I was doing. . . ."

"wʌt?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "ju wʊdn əv hʌntəd mi daʊn?"

"What?" she demanded. "You wouldn't have hunted me down?"

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪ wəd hæv," hi sɛɾ ɪndɪɡnənli. "aɪɾ əv dʒʌs bɪn mɔɹ kɛɹfəl, ən pɝhæps kʌm bɛɾɝ pɹipɛɹd. aɪ wɛn ɔf hʌntɪŋ bɔɹz wɪð ə ɹæbət naɪf ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə spɪɹ!"

"Of course I would have," he said indignantly. "I'd have just been more careful, and perhaps come better prepared. I went off hunting boars with a rabbit knife instead of a spear!"

sɪuən sɛt ðə foʊldəd ʃɝɾ ɑn tɑp ə ði ʌðɝz, ðən pɪkt ʌp ðə stæk. ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə sʌfɝɪŋ lʊk. "aɪ wɪl də maɪ bɛs tə pɹitɛn ðət jə dɪdn dʒʌs kəmpɛɹ mi tə ə bɔɹ, bɹaɪn. kaɪnli bi ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ kɔʃəs wɪð jəɹ tʌŋ. ʌðɝwaɪz, jəl faɪn jɝsɛlf wɪθaʊɾ ə meɪdsɝvənt, ən jəl əv tə lɛt ðoʊz leɪɾiz ɪn ðə kæmp teɪk ʌp jəɹ lɔnʒɹi."

Siuan set the folded shirt on top of the others, then picked up the stack. She gave him a suffering look. "I will do my best to pretend that you didn't just compare me to a boar, Bryne. Kindly be a little more cautious with your tongue. Otherwise, you'll find yourself without a maidservant, and you'll have to let those ladies in the camp take up your laundry."

hi ɡeɪv əɹ ə bɪmjuz lʊk. ðən i dʒʌs læft. ʃi feɪld ət kipɪŋ əɹ oʊn ɡɹɪn tə hɝsɛlf.

He gave her a bemused look. Then he just laughed. She failed at keeping her own grin to herself.

wɛl, æftɝ ðəɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒ, hi wəd noʊ hu wɑz ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðɪs əsoʊsieɪʃən.

Well, after that exchange, he would know who was in control of this association.

bʌt . . . laɪt! waɪ hæd ʃi toʊld ɪm əbaʊt ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ? ʃid ɹɛɹli toʊld ɛniwʌn əbaʊt ðæt! əz ʃi pæk ðə ʃɝts ɪn ɪz tʃɹʌŋk, ʃi ɡlænst ət bɹaɪn, hu wɑz stɪl ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən tʃʌklɪŋ.

But . . . Light! Why had she told him about the Foretelling? She'd rarely told anyone about that! As she packed the shirts in his trunk, she glanced at Bryne, who was still shaking his head and chuckling.

wən ʌðɝ oʊðz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əv ə hoʊld ɑn mi, ʃi θɔt. wən aɪm sɝɾən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz duɪŋ wʌt hiz səpoʊz tə, pɝhæps ðəɹ wɪl bi taɪm. fəɹ wʌns, aɪm æktʃəli  stɑɹɾɪŋ tə lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə biɪŋ dʌn wɪð ðɪs kwɛst. haʊ ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl.

When other oaths no longer have a hold on me, she thought. When I'm certain the Dragon Reborn is doing what he is supposed to, perhaps there will be time. For once, I'm actually starting to look forward to being done with this quest. How remarkable.

"ju ʃəd bi bɛɾɪŋ daʊn, sɪuən," bɹaɪn sɛd.

"You should be bedding down, Siuan," Bryne said.

"ɪts ɝli jɛt," ʃi sɛd.

"It's early yet," she said.

"jɛs, bʌɾ ɪts sʌnsɛt. ɛvɹi θɝd deɪ jə bɛd daʊn ʌnkɛɹɪktɝɪstɪkli ɝli, wɛɹɪŋ ðəɾ ɑd ɹɪŋ juv hɪɾən bɪtwin ðə kʊʃənz ə jəɹ pælət." hi tɝn oʊvɝ ə peɪpɝ ɑn ɪz dɛsk.

"Yes, but it's sunset. Every third day you bed down uncharacteristically early, wearing that odd ring you have hidden between the cushions of your pallet." He turned over a paper on his desk.

"pliz ɡɪv maɪ kaɪn ɹɪɡɑɹdz tə ði æmɪɝlɪn."

"Please give my kind regards to the Amyrlin."

ʃi tɝn təwɔɹd hɪm, slæk-dʒɔd. hi kʊdnt noʊ əbaʊt tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, kəd hi? ʃi kɑɾ ɪm smaɪlɪŋ ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən. wɛl, pɝhæps i dɪdnt noʊ əbaʊt tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, bʌt hiɾ ɑbviəsli ɡɛs ðət ðə ɹɪŋ ən əɹ skɛdʒʊl hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð kəmjunəkeɪɾɪŋ wɪð ɛɡwin. slaɪ. hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə hɪz peɪpɝz əɾ əɹ əz ʃi pæst, ən ɪz aɪz hæɾ ə twɪŋkəl tə ðɛm.

She turned toward him, slack-jawed. He couldn't know about Tel'aran'rhiod, could he? She caught him smiling in satisfaction. Well, perhaps he didn't know about Tel'aran'rhiod, but he'd obviously guessed that the ring and her schedule had something to do with communicating with Egwene. Sly. He glanced over the top of his papers at her as she passed, and his eyes had a twinkle to them.

"ɪnsʌfɝəbəl mæn," ʃi mʌɾɝd, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn əɹ pæləɾ ən dɪsmɪsɪŋ əɹ ɡloʊb ə laɪt.

"Insufferable man," she muttered, sitting down on her pallet and dismissing her globe of light.

ðən ʃi ʃipɪʃli fɪʃt aʊt ðə ɹɪŋ tɛɹæŋɡɹil ən pʊɾ ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, tɝn əɹ bæk ɑn ɪm ən leɪ daʊn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɪl hɝsɛlf tə slip. ʃi meɪd sɝɾən tə ɹaɪz ɝli ɛvɹi θɝd deɪ soʊ ðət ʃid bi taɪɝɾ ət naɪt. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd pʊt hɝsɛlf tə slip əz izəli əz ɛɡwin dɪd.

Then she sheepishly fished out the ring ter'angreal and put it around her neck, turned her back on him and lay down, trying to will herself to sleep. She made certain to rise early every third day so that she'd be tired at night. She wished she could put herself to sleep as easily as Egwene did.

ɪnsʌfɝəbəl . . . ɪnsʌfɝəbəl mæn! ʃiɾ əv tə də sʌmθɪŋ tə ɡɛt bæk ət hɪm. maɪs ɪn ðə bɛdʃits. ðət wəd bi ə ɡʊd peɪbæk.

Insufferable . . . insufferable man! She'd have to do something to get back at him. Mice in the bedsheets. That would be a good payback.

ʃi leɪ fəɹ tu lɔŋ ə taɪm, bʌɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli koʊks hɝsɛlf tə slip, smaɪlɪŋ feɪnli tə hɝsɛlf ət ðə pɹɑspɛkt ʌv ən æpt ɹivɛnʒ. ʃi əwoʊk ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd wɛɹɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ə skændələs, bɛɹli kʌvɝɪŋ ʃɪft. ʃi jɛlpt, ɪmiɾiətli ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ ðət - θɹu kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən - wɪð ə ɡɹin dʒɹɛs.

She lay for too long a time, but eventually coaxed herself to sleep, smiling faintly to herself at the prospect of an apt revenge. She awoke in Tel'aran'rhiod wearing nothing but a scandalous, barely covering shift. She yelped, immediately replacing that - through concentration - with a green dress.

ɡɹin? waɪ ɡɹin? ʃi meɪɾ ɪt blu. laɪt! haʊ wɑz ɪt ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ɔlweɪz soʊ ɡʊɾ ət kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ θɪŋz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd waɪl sɪuən kəd bɛɹli kip əɹ kloʊðɪŋ fɹəm swɪtʃɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹi aɪɾəl θɔt? ɪt mʌst əv sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə fæk ðət sɪuən hæd tə wɛɹ ðɪs ɪnfɪɹiɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil kɑpi, wɪtʃ dɪdnt wɝk əz wɛl əz ði ɝɪdʒənəl. ɪt meɪɾ əɹ lʊk ɪnsəbstæntʃəl tə ʌðɝz u sɔ hɝ.

Green? Why green? She made it blue. Light! How was it that Egwene was always so good at controlling things in Tel'aran'rhiod while Siuan could barely keep her clothing from switching at every idle thought? It must have something to do with the fact that Siuan had to wear this inferior ter'angreal copy, which didn't work as well as the original. It made her look insubstantial to others who saw her.

ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp, sɝaʊndəd baɪ tɛns. ðə flæps ʌv ɛni ɡɪvən stʃɹʌktʃɝ wəd bi oʊpən wʌn moʊmənt, ðən kloʊz ðə nɛkst. ðə skaɪ wɑz tʃɹʌbəl baɪ ə vaɪələnt, jɛt stʃɹeɪnʒli saɪlənt, stɔɹm. kjʊɹiəs, bʌt θɪŋz wɝ ɔfən stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, wɪlɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə əpɪɹ ɪn ðə stʌɾi ʌv ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. wən ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz, ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ. ə smɔl, wʊd-pænəld ɹum wɪð ə staʊt dɛsk ən ə teɪbəl fəɹ stʃɹæpɪŋz.

She was standing in the middle of the Aes Sedai camp, surrounded by tents. The flaps of any given structure would be open one moment, then closed the next. The sky was troubled by a violent, yet strangely silent, storm. Curious, but things were often strange in Tel'aran'rhiod. She closed her eyes, willing herself to appear in the study of the Mistress of Novices in the White Tower. When she opened her eyes, she was there. A small, wood-paneled room with a stout desk and a table for strappings.

ʃi wʊɾə laɪk tə hæv ði ɝɪdʒənəl ɹɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn hæd teɪkən ðət wʌn wɪð hɝ. ʃi ʃəd bi θæŋkfəl fəɹ ivən ə smɔl kætʃ, əz əɹ fɑðɝ hæd bɪn fɑn ə seɪɪŋ. ʃi cʊɾə bɪn lɛft wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ʌv ðə ɹɪŋz. ðə sɪɾɝz θɔt ðɪs wʌn hæd bɪn wɪð lin wən ʃid bɪn kæptʃɝd.

She would have liked to have the original ring, but Elayne had taken that one with her. She should be thankful for even a small catch, as her father had been fond of saying. She could have been left without any of the rings. The Sitters thought this one had been with Leane when she'd been captured.

wɑz lin ɔl ɹaɪt? əɾ ɛni moʊmənt, ðə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn kəɾ ɑp fəɹ ɛksəkjuʃən. sɪuən nu ɔl tu wɛl haʊ spaɪtfəl ɪleɪɾə kəd bi; ʃi stɪl fɛlt ə stæb ə sɑɹoʊ wən ʃi θɔɾ ə pʊɹ ɔlɹɪk.

Was Leane all right? At any moment, the false Amyrlin could opt for execution. Siuan knew all too well how spiteful Elaida could be; she still felt a stab of sorrow when she thought of poor Alric.

hæɾ ɪleɪɾə fɛlt ə sɪŋɡəl moʊmən ʌv ɡɪlt oʊvɝ mɝɾɝɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ ɪn koʊl blʌd, bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən ʃi wɑz tɛɹɪŋ daʊn hæd bɪn pɹɑpɝli dɪpoʊzd?

Had Elaida felt a single moment of guilt over murdering a Warder in cold blood, before the woman she was tearing down had been properly deposed?

"ə sɔɹd, sɪuən?" ɛɡwinz vɔɪs sʌɾənli æskt. "ðæts nɑvəl."

"A sword, Siuan?" Egwene's voice suddenly asked. "That's novel."

sɪuən lʊk daʊn, ʃɑk tə faɪn hɝsɛlf hoʊldɪŋ ə blʌɾi sɔɹd, laɪkli ɪntɛndəd fəɹ ɪleɪɾəz hɑɹt. ʃi meɪɾ ɪt vænɪʃ, ðən ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɛɡwin. ðə ɡɝl lʊk ðə pɑɹɾ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn, wɛɹɪŋ ðət mæɡnɪfəsənt ɡoʊldən ɡaʊn, hɝ bɹaʊn hɛɹ ɪn ən ɪntʃɹəkəɾ ɝeɪnʒmənt sɛt wɪð pɝlz. hɝ feɪs wɑzn eɪdʒləs jɛt, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət ðə kɑm sɝɛnəɾi ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪn fækt, ʃi sim tə hæv ɡɹoʊn mɛʒɝəbli bɛɾɝ ət ðət sɪns əɹ kæptʃɝ.

Siuan looked down, shocked to find herself holding a bloody sword, likely intended for Elaida's heart. She made it vanish, then regarded Egwene. The girl looked the part of the Amyrlin, wearing that magnificent golden gown, her brown hair in an intricate arrangement set with pearls. Her face wasn't ageless yet, but Egwene was getting very good at the calm serenity of an Aes Sedai. In fact, she seemed to have grown measurably better at that since her capture.

"ju lʊk wɛl, mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛd.

"You look well, Mother," Siuan said.

"θæŋk ju," ɛɡwin sɛd, wɪð ə feɪn smaɪl. ʃi ʃoʊd mɔɹ ə hɝsɛlf ɝaʊn sɪuən ðən ʃi dɪd ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ boʊθ nu haʊ hɛvəli ɛɡwin hæd ɹɪlaɪɾ ɑn sɪuənz titʃɪŋ tə ɡɛt wɛɹ ʃi wɑz.

"Thank you," Egwene said, with a faint smile. She showed more of herself around Siuan than she did the others. They both knew how heavily Egwene had relied on Siuan's teaching to get where she was.

ðoʊ ʃid pɹɑbli hæv meɪɾ ɪt ðəɹ ɛniweɪ, sɪuən ədmɪɾəd. dʒʌs nɑt kwaɪɾ əz kwɪkli.

Though she'd probably have made it there anyway, Siuan admitted. Just not quite as quickly.

ɛɡwin ɡlænst ət ðə ɹum ɝaʊn ðɛm, ðən ɡɹɪməs feɪnli. "aɪ ɹilaɪz aɪ sədʒɛstəd ðɪs loʊkeɪʃən læs taɪm, bʌɾ aɪ hæv sin ɪnʌf ə ðɪs ɹum leɪtli. əl mit jə ɪn ðə nɑvəsɪz' daɪnɪŋ hɔl." ʃi vænɪʃt.

Egwene glanced at the room around them, then grimaced faintly. "I realize I suggested this location last time, but I have seen enough of this room lately. I will meet you in the novices' dining hall." She vanished.

ən ɑd tʃɔɪs, bʌt vɛɹi ənlaɪkli tə kənsil ənwɔntɪɾ ɪɹz. sɪuən ən ɛɡwin wɝn ði oʊnli wʌnz u juz tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd fəɹ klændɛstɪn miɾɪŋz. sɪuən kloʊzd əɹ aɪz - ʃi dɪdnt nid tə, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə hɛlp əɹ - ən ɪmædʒən ðə nɑvəsɪz' daɪnɪŋ hɔl, wɪð ɪts ɹoʊz ə bɛntʃɪz ən ɪts bɛɹ wɔlz. wən ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz, ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ, əz wɑz ɛɡwin. ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛɾəld bæk ən ə mədʒɛstɪk stʌf tʃɛɹ əpɪɹd bɪhaɪn hɝ, kætʃɪŋ əɹ ɡɹeɪsfəli əz ʃi sæt. sɪuən dɪdn tʃɹʌs hɝsɛlf tə də ɛniθɪŋ soʊ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd; ʃi sɪmpli sæt daʊn ɑn wʌn ə ðə bɛntʃɪz.

An odd choice, but very unlikely to conceal unwanted ears. Siuan and Egwene weren't the only ones who used Tel'aran'rhiod for clandestine meetings. Siuan closed her eyes - she didn't need to, but it seemed to help her - and imagined the novices' dining hall, with its rows of benches and its bare walls. When she opened her eyes, she was there, as was Egwene. The Amyrlin settled back and a majestic stuffed chair appeared behind her, catching her gracefully as she sat. Siuan didn't trust herself to do anything so complicated; she simply sat down on one of the benches.

"aɪ θɪŋk wi meɪ wɑnə stɑɹt miɾɪŋ mɔɹ fɹikwənli, mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛd, tæpɪŋ ðə teɪbəl əz ʃi ɔɹɾɝd əɹ θɔts.

"I think we may want to start meeting more frequently, Mother," Siuan said, tapping the table as she ordered her thoughts.

"oʊ?" ɛɡwin æskt, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾɝ. "hæz sʌmθɪŋ hæpənd?"

"Oh?" Egwene asked, sitting up straighter. "Has something happened?"

"sɛvɹəl sʌmθɪŋz," sɪuən sɛd, "æn aɪm əfɹeɪɾ ə fju ʌv əm smɛl əz ɹaɪp əz læst wiks kætʃ."

"Several somethings," Siuan said, "and I'm afraid a few of them smell as ripe as last week's catch."

"tɛl mi."

"Tell me."

"wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑz ɪn əɹ kæmp," sɪuən sɛd. ʃi hædnt wɑntəd tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðət tu fɹikwənli. ðə nɑlədʒ meɪɾ əɹ skɪn kɹɔl.

"One of the Forsaken was in our camp," Siuan said. She hadn't wanted to think about that too frequently. The knowledge made her skin crawl.

"ɪz ɛniwʌn dɛd?" ɛɡwin æskt, vɔɪs kɑm ðoʊ hɝ aɪz lʊk tə bi stil.

"Is anyone dead?" Egwene asked, voice calm though her eyes looked to be steel.

"noʊ, blɛs ðə laɪt," sɪuən sɛd. "ʌðɝ ðən ðoʊz jə ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ əbaʊt. ɹoʊmændə meɪd ðə kənɛkʃən. ɛɡwin, ðə kɹitʃɝ hæd bɪn wɪð əs fəɹ səm taɪm, ɪn haɪɾɪŋ."

"No, bless the Light," Siuan said. "Other than those you already know about. Romanda made the connection. Egwene, the creature had been with us for some time, in hiding."

"hu?"

"Who?"

"dɛlænə moʊzɑleɪn," sɪuən sɛd. "ɔɹ əɹ sɝvɪŋ wʊmən, hɑlimə. moʊs laɪkli hɑlimə, əz aɪv noʊn dɛlænə fəɹ ə ɡɹeɪt lɔŋ taɪm." ɛɡwinz aɪz waɪɾənd dʒʌs feɪnli. hɑlimə hæd weɪɾəd ɑn ɛɡwin. ɛɡwin hæd bɪn tʌtʃt ən sɝv baɪ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ʃi tʊk ðə nuz wɛl. laɪk ən æmɪɝlɪn.

"Delana Mosalaine," Siuan said. "Or her serving woman, Halima. Most likely Halima, as I've known Delana for a great long time." Egwene's eyes widened just faintly. Halima had waited on Egwene. Egwene had been touched and served by one of the Forsaken. She took the news well. Like an Amyrlin.

"bʌɾ æneɪjə wɑz kɪl baɪ ə mæn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wɝ ðoʊz mɝɾɝz dɪfɹənt?"

"But Anaiya was killed by a man," Egwene said. "Were those murders different?"

"noʊ. æneɪjə wɑzn mɝɾɝd baɪ ə mæn, bʌt baɪ ə wʊmən wildɪŋ seɪɾɪn. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn - ɪts ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət meɪks sɛns."

"No. Anaiya wasn't murdered by a man, but by a woman wielding saidin. It must have been - it's the only thing that makes sense."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd sloʊli. ɛniθɪŋ wɑz pɑsəbəl wɛɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz kənsɝnd. sɪuən smaɪld ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən ən pɹaɪd. ðɪs ɡɝl wɑz lɝnɪŋ tə bi æmɪɝlɪn. laɪt, ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn!

Egwene nodded slowly. Anything was possible where the Dark One was concerned. Siuan smiled in satisfaction and pride. This girl was learning to be Amyrlin. Light, she was Amyrlin!

"ðɛɹz mɔɹ?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"There's more?" Egwene asked.

"nɑt mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɑn ðɪs tɑpɪk," sɪuən sɛd. "ðeɪ ɡɑɾ əweɪ fɹəm ʌs, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. dɪsəpɪɹd ðə vɛɹi deɪ wi dɪskʌvɝd ðɛm."

"Not much more on this topic," Siuan said. "They got away from us, unfortunately. Disappeared the very day we discovered them."

"wʌt wɔɹn ðɛm, aɪ wʌndɝ."

"What warned them, I wonder."

"wɛl, ðəɾ ɪnvɑlvz wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ θɪŋz aɪ nid tə tɛl ju." sɪuən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ðə wɝst ʌv ɪt wɑz aʊt, bʌt ðɪs nɛks pɑɹt wʊdn bi mʌtʃ iziɝ tə stʌmək. "ðɛɹ wɑz ə miɾɪŋ ə ðə hɔl ðət deɪ, ətɛndəd baɪ dɛlænə. ɪn ðət miɾɪŋ, ən æʃəmən ənaʊns ðəɾ i kəd sɛns ə mæn tʃænəlɪŋ ɪn ðə kæmp. wi θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ ɪnfɔɹm hɝ. ɪt wɑzn əntɪl æftɝ dɛlænə flɛd ðət wi meɪd ðə kənɛkʃən. ɪt wɑz ðət seɪm æʃəmən u toʊld əs ðəɾ ɪz fɛloʊ hæɾ ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ə wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl seɪɾɪn."

"Well, that involves one of the other things I need to tell you." Siuan took a deep breath. The worst of it was out, but this next part wouldn't be much easier to stomach. "There was a meeting of the Hall that day, attended by Delana. In that meeting, an Asha'man announced that he could sense a man channeling in the camp. We think that is what informed her. It wasn't until after Delana fled that we made the connection. It was that same Asha'man who told us that his fellow had encountered a woman who could channel saidin."

"ænd waɪ wɑz ən æʃəmən ɪn ðə kæmp?" ɛɡwin æskt kuli.

"And why was an Asha'man in the camp?" Egwene asked coolly.

"hid bɪn sɛn əz ən ɛnvɔɪ," sɪuən ɪkspleɪnd. "fɹʌm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. mʌðɝ, ɪɾ əpɪɹz səm ə ðə mɛn u fɑloʊ ælθɹ əv bɑndəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"He'd been sent as an envoy," Siuan explained. "From the Dragon Reborn. Mother, it appears some of the men who follow al'Thor have bonded Aes Sedai."

ɛɡwin blɪŋkt ə sɪŋɡəl taɪm. "jɛs. aɪ hæd hɝd ɹumɝz ə ðɪs. aɪ hæd hoʊp ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd. dɪd ðɪs æʃəmən seɪ hu ɡeɪv ɹænd pɝmɪʃən tə kəmɪt sətʃ ən ətʃɹɑsəɾi?"

Egwene blinked a single time. "Yes. I had heard rumors of this. I had hoped that they were exaggerated. Did this Asha'man say who gave Rand permission to commit such an atrocity?"

"hiz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," sɪuən sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk i filz i nidz pɝmɪʃən.

"He's the Dragon Reborn," Siuan said, grimacing. "I don't think he feels he needs permission.

bʌt, ɪn ɪz dɪfɛns, ɪɾ əpɪɹz i dɪdnt noʊ ɪt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. ðə wɪmən ɪz mɛn bɑndəd wɝ sɛn baɪ ɪleɪɾə tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə blæk taʊɝ."

But, in his defense, it appears he didn't know it was happening. The women his men bonded were sent by Elaida to destroy the Black Tower."

"jɛs." ɛɡwin faɪnəli ʃoʊɾ ə slɪvɝ ʌv ɪmoʊʃən. "soʊ ðə ɹumɝz ɑɹ ækjɝət. ɔl tu ækjɝət." hɝ bjuɾəfəl dʒɹɛs ɹɪteɪn ɪts ʃeɪp, bʌt blɛd tə ə dip bɹaʊn ɪn kʌlɝ, laɪk il kloʊðɪŋ. ɛɡwin dɪdn sim tə noʊɾəs ðə tʃeɪnʒ. "wɪl ɪleɪɾəz ɹeɪn ə dɪzæstɝz nɛvɝ sis?"

"Yes." Egwene finally showed a sliver of emotion. "So the rumors are accurate. All too accurate." Her beautiful dress retained its shape, but bled to a deep brown in color, like Aiel clothing. Egwene didn't seem to notice the change. "Will Elaida's reign of disasters never cease?"

sɪuən dʒʌst ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "wiv bɪn ɔfɝd fɔɹɾi-sɛvən æʃəmən tə bɑn əz ɹɛstɪtuʃən, ʌv sɔɹts, fəɹ ðə wɪmən ælθɹz mɛn bɑndəd. hɑɹdli ə fɛɹ tʃɹeɪd, bʌt ðə hɔl dɪsaɪɾɪd tə æksɛp ði ɔfɝ nʌnðəlɛs."

Siuan just shook her head. "We've been offered forty-seven Asha'man to bond as restitution, of sorts, for the women al'Thor's men bonded. Hardly a fair trade, but the Hall decided to accept the offer nonetheless."

"æz wɛl ðeɪ ʃəd hæv," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wi ʃæl əv tə dil wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡənz fulɪʃnəs əɾ ə leɪɾɝ deɪt. pɝhæps ɪz mɛn æktəd wɪθaʊɾ ɪz dɝɛkt ɔɹɾɝz, bʌt ɹænd mʌs teɪk ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi.

"As well they should have," Egwene said. "We shall have to deal with the Dragon's foolishness at a later date. Perhaps his men acted without his direct orders, but Rand must take responsibility.

mɛn. bɑndɪŋ wɪmən!"

Men. Bonding women!"

"ðeɪ kleɪm seɪɾɪn ɪz klɛnzd," sɪuən sɛd.

"They claim saidin is cleansed," Siuan said.

ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, bʌt dɪd nɑɾ əbdʒɛkt. "jɛs," ʃi sɛd, "aɪ səpoʊz ðət maɪt bi ə ɹizənəbəl pɑsəbɪləɾi. wɪl nid fɝðɝ kɑnfɝmeɪʃən, ʌv kɔɹs. bʌt ðə teɪn ɝaɪvd wən ɔl simd wʌn; waɪ ʃəɾ ɪt nɑt liv wən ɔl simz tə bi əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ pjʊɹ mædnəs?"

Egwene raised an eyebrow, but did not object. "Yes," she said, "I suppose that might be a reasonable possibility. We will need further confirmation, of course. But the taint arrived when all seemed won; why should it not leave when all seems to be approaching pure madness?"

"aɪ hædn kənsɪɾɝd ɪt ðət weɪ," sɪuən sɛd. "wɛl, wʌt ʃəd wi du, mʌðɝ?"

"I hadn't considered it that way," Siuan said. "Well, what should we do, Mother?"

"lɛt ðə hɔl dil wɪð ɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪt simz ðeɪv mæɾɝz ɪn hænd."

"Let the Hall deal with it," Egwene said. "It seems they have matters in hand."

"ðeɪd bi bɛɾɝ ət kipɪŋ əm ɪn hæn ɪf jud ɹɪtɝn, mʌðɝ."

"They'd be better at keeping them in hand if you'd return, Mother."

"ɪvɛntʃəwəli," ɛɡwin sɛd. ʃi sæt bæk ən leɪst əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪn əɹ læp, sʌmhaʊ lʊkɪŋ fɑɹ oʊldɝ ðən əɹ feɪs wəd sədʒɛst. "maɪ wɝk ɪz hɪɹ, fəɹ naʊ. jəl əv tə si ðət ðə hɔl dʌz əz ɪt ʃʊd. aɪ hæv ɡɹeɪt feɪθ ɪn ju."

"Eventually," Egwene said. She sat back and laced her fingers in her lap, somehow looking far older than her face would suggest. "My work is here, for now. You'll have to see that the Hall does as it should. I have great faith in you."

"æn ɪts əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd, mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛd, kipɪŋ əɹ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ɪnsaɪd. "bʌɾ aɪm luzɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðɛm. ləleɪn əz bɪɡʌn tə sɛt hɝsɛlf ʌp əz ə sɛkən æmɪɝlɪn - ən ɪz duɪŋ ɪt baɪ pɹitɛndɪŋ tə səpɔɹt ju. ʃiz sin ðəɾ əpɪɹɪŋ tə ækt ɪn jəɹ neɪm sɝvz hɝsɛlf."

"And it's appreciated, Mother," Siuan said, keeping her frustration inside. "But I'm losing control of them. Lelaine has begun to set herself up as a second Amyrlin - and is doing it by pretending to support you. She's seen that appearing to act in your name serves herself."

ɛɡwin pɝst əɹ lɪps. "aɪ wʊɾə θɔt ɹoʊmændə wəd teɪk ði ædvæntɪdʒ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðət ʃi dɪskʌvɝd ðə fɔɹseɪkən."

Egwene pursed her lips. "I would have thought Romanda would take the advantage, considering that she discovered the Forsaken."

"aɪ θɪŋk ʃi əsumd ʃid hoʊl ði ædvæntɪdʒ," sɪuən sɛd, "bʌt ʃi spɛn tu lɔŋ bæskɪŋ ɪn əɹ vɪktɝi. ləleɪn hæz, wɪð noʊ smɔl ɛfɝt, bɪkʌm ðə moʊs dɪvoʊɾəd sɝvən ə ði æmɪɝlɪn u hæz ɛvɝ lɪvd. jə wəd θɪŋk ðət jə ən ʃi wɝ ðə kloʊsəst ə kɑnfədæns, tə hɪɹ əɹ spik! ʃiz əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪd mi əz əɹ ətɛndənt, ən itʃ taɪm ðə hɔl mits ɪts 'ɛɡwin wɑntəd ðɪs' ən 'ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ ɛɡwin sɛd wən wi dɪd ðæt.' "

"I think she assumed she'd hold the advantage," Siuan said, "but she spent too long basking in her victory. Lelaine has, with no small effort, become the most devoted servant of the Amyrlin who has ever lived. You would think that you and she were the closest of confidants, to hear her speak! She's appropriated me as her attendant, and each time the Hall meets it's 'Egwene wanted this' and 'Remember what Egwene said when we did that.' "

"klɛvɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Clever," Egwene said.

"bɹɪljənt," sɪuən sɛd, saɪɪŋ. "bʌt wi nu wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz ɪvɛntʃəwəli gɑnə klɔ hɝ weɪ əhɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝ. aɪ kip daɪvɝɾɪŋ əɹ təwɔɹd ɹoʊmændə, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ lɔŋ aɪ kən kip əɹ dɪstʃɹæktəd."

"Brilliant," Siuan said, sighing. "But we knew one of them was eventually going to claw her way ahead of the other. I keep diverting her toward Romanda, but I don't know how long I can keep her distracted."

"du jəɹ bɛst," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌt doʊnt wɝi ɪf ləleɪn ɹəfjuzəz tə bi daɪvɝɾɪd."

"Do your best," Egwene said. "But don't worry if Lelaine refuses to be diverted."

sɪuən fɹaʊnd. "bʌt ʃiz jusɝpɪŋ jəɹ pleɪs!"

Siuan frowned. "But she's usurping your place!"

"baɪ bɪldɪŋ əpɑn ɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. ʃi faɪnəli noʊɾəst ðəɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs hæd tʃeɪnʒd tə bɹaʊn, fəɹ ʃi swɪtʃt ɪt bæk ɪn ə hɑɹtbit, nɑt bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən. "ləleɪnz ɡæmbɪt wɪl oʊnli səksiɾ ɪf aɪ feɪl tə ɹɪtɝn. ʃiz juzɪŋ mi əz ə sɔɹs ʌv əθɔɹəɾi. wən aɪ ɹɪtɝn, ʃɪl əv noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə æksɛp maɪ liɾɝʃɪp. ʃɪl əv spɛn ɔl ə hɝ ɛfɝt bɪldɪŋ mi ʌp."

"By building upon it," Egwene said, smiling. She finally noticed that her dress had changed to brown, for she switched it back in a heartbeat, not breaking the conversation. "Lelaine's gambit will only succeed if I fail to return. She is using me as a source of authority. When I return, she'll have no choice but to accept my leadership. She'll have spent all of her effort building me up."

"æn ɪf jə doʊn ɹɪtɝn, mʌðɝ?" sɪuən æsk sɔfli.

"And if you don't return, Mother?" Siuan asked softly.

"ðɛn ɪɾəl bi bɛɾɝ fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hæv ə stʃɹɔŋ liɾɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪf ləleɪn əz bɪn ðə wʌn tə sɪkjʊɹ ðət stʃɹɛŋkθ, ðən soʊ bi ɪt."

"Then it will be better for the Aes Sedai to have a strong leader," Egwene said. "If Lelaine has been the one to secure that strength, then so be it."

"ʃi hæz ɡʊd ɹizən tə meɪk sɝɾən jə doʊn ɹɪtɝn, jə noʊ," sɪuən sɛd. "æt ðə vɛɹi list, ʃiz bɛɾɪŋ əɡɛns ju."

"She has good reason to make certain you don't return, you know," Siuan said. "At the very least, she's betting against you."

"wɛl, ʃi kæn vɛɹi wɛl bi bleɪm fəɹ ðæt." ɛɡwin lɛt daʊn əɹ ɡɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ə ɡɹɪmɑs. "aɪd bi tɛmptəd tə bɛɾ əɡɛns maɪsɛlf, ɪf aɪ wɝ ɑn ði aʊtsaɪd. jəl sɪmpli hæv tə dil wɪð hɝ, sɪuən. aɪ kæn lɛt maɪsɛlf bi dɪstʃɹæktəd. nɑt wən aɪ si soʊ mʌtʃ pətɛnʃəl fəɹ səksɛs hɪɹ, ən nɑt wən ðəɹ ɪz ən ivən ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɹaɪs fəɹ feɪljɝ."

"Well, she can't very well be blamed for that." Egwene let down her guard enough to show a grimace. "I'd be tempted to bet against myself, if I were on the outside. You'll simply have to deal with her, Siuan. I can't let myself be distracted. Not when I see so much potential for success here, and not when there is an even greater price for failure."

sɪuən nu ðət stʌbɝn sɛt tə ɛɡwinz dʒɔ. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ pɝsweɪɾɪŋ əɹ tənaɪt. sɪuən wəd sɪmpli hæv tə tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn dʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ nɛks miɾɪŋ.

Siuan knew that stubborn set to Egwene's jaw. There would be no persuading her tonight. Siuan would simply have to try again during their next meeting.

ɔl ʌv ɪt - ðə klɛnzɪŋ, ði æʃəmən, ðə kɹʌmbəlɪŋ ə ðə taʊɝ - meɪɾ əɹ ʃɪvɝ ənkʌmftəbli. ðoʊ ʃid bɪn pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðiz deɪz fəɹ moʊst ə hɝ laɪf, ɪt wɑz stɪl ənsɛɾəlɪŋ tə hæv əm faɪnəli ɝaɪv. "ðə læs bæɾəl ɹɪli ɪz kʌmɪŋ," sɪuən sɛd, moʊsli tə hɝsɛlf.

All of it - the cleansing, the Asha'man, the crumbling of the Tower - made her shiver uncomfortably. Though she'd been preparing for these days for most of her life, it was still unsettling to have them finally arrive. "The Last Battle really is coming," Siuan said, mostly to herself.

"ɪɾ ɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd, vɔɪs sɑləm.

"It is," Egwene said, voice solemn.

"æn aɪm gɑnə feɪs ɪt wɪð bɛɹli ə lɪk ə maɪ fɔɹmɝ paʊɝ," sɪuən sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ.

"And I'm going to face it with barely a lick of my former power," Siuan said, grimacing.

"wɛl, pɝhæps wi kən ɡɛt jə ən æŋɡɹil wʌns ðə taʊɝ ɪz hoʊl əɡɛn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wil bi juzɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɪv wən wi ɹaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ."

"Well, perhaps we can get you an angreal once the Tower is whole again," Egwene said. "We'll be using everything we have when we ride against the Shadow."

sɪuən smaɪld. "ðæt wəd bi naɪs, bʌt nɑt nɛsəsɛɹi. aɪm dʒʌst ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ aʊɾ ə hæbət, aɪ səpoʊz.

Siuan smiled. "That would be nice, but not necessary. I'm just grumbling out of habit, I suppose.

aɪm æktʃəli  lɝnɪŋ tə dil wɪð maɪ . . . nu sɪtʃueɪʃən. ɪts nɑt soʊ dɪfəkəl tə stʌmək, naʊ ðəɾ aɪ si ɪts əz səm ædvæntɪdʒɪz."

I'm actually learning to deal with my . . . new situation. It's not so difficult to stomach, now that I see that it has some advantages."

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd, əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌɾ ædvæntɪdʒɪz ðəɹ kəd bi ɪn lɛsən paʊɝ.

Egwene frowned, as if trying to figure out what advantages there could be in lessened power.

faɪnəli, ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɪleɪn wʌns mɛnʃən ə ɹum tə mi ɪn ðə taʊɝ, fɪld wɪð ɑbʒɛkts ə paʊɝ. aɪ əsum ɪt ɹɪli ɪɡzɪsts?"

Finally, she shook her head. "Elayne once mentioned a room to me in the Tower, filled with objects of power. I assume it really exists?"

"ʌv kɔɹs," sɪuən sɛd. "ðə beɪsmən stɔɹɹum. ɪts ɪn ðə sɛkən lɛvəl ə ðə beɪsmənt, ɑn ðə nɔɹθist saɪd. lɪɾəl ɹum wɪð ə pleɪn wʊɾən dɔɹ, bʌt jə kæn mɪs ɪt. ɪts ði oʊnli wʌn ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ ðəɾ ɪz lɑkt."

"Of course," Siuan said. "The basement storeroom. It's in the second level of the basement, on the northeast side. Little room with a plain wooden door, but you can't miss it. It's the only one in the hallway that is locked."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf. "wɛl, aɪ kæn dɪfiɾ ɪleɪɾə θɹu bɹut fɔɹs. stɪl, ɪts naɪs tə noʊ ʌv ðæt. ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl tə ɹipɔɹt?"

Egwene nodded to herself. "Well, I can't defeat Elaida through brute force. Still, it is nice to know of that. Is there anything else remarkable to report?"

"nɑɾ ət ðə moʊmənt, mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛd.

"Not at the moment, Mother," Siuan said.

"ðɛn ɹɪtɝn ən ɡɛt səm slip." ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ænd nɛks taɪm, wɪl miɾ ɪn tu deɪz.

"Then return and get some sleep." Egwene hesitated. "And next time, we'll meet in two days.

hɪɹ ɪn ðə nɑvəsɪz' daɪnɪŋ hɔl, ðoʊ wi meɪ wɑnə bɪɡɪn miɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌs ðɪs pleɪs. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə fɔɹseɪkən ɪn əɹ kæmp, aɪd bɛt hæf maɪ fɑðɝz ɪn ðət ðɛɹz wʌn spaɪɪŋ ɑn ðə waɪt taʊɝ tu."

Here in the novices' dining hall, though we may want to begin meeting out in the city. I don't trust this place. If there was a Forsaken in our camp, I'd bet half my father's inn that there's one spying on the White Tower too."

sɪuən nɑɾəd. "vɛɹi wɛl." ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, ən sun faʊn hɝsɛlf blɪŋkɪŋ əweɪk bæk ɪn bɹaɪnz tɛnt. ðə kændəl wɑz aʊt, ən ʃi kəd hɪɹ bɹaɪn bɹiðɪŋ kwaɪətli fɹəm ɪz pæləɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt. ʃi sæɾ ʌp ən lʊkt əkɹɔs ət hɪm, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz tu dɑɹk tə si ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ʃædoʊz. stʃɹeɪnʒli, æftɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt fɔɹseɪkən ən æʃəmən, ðə stɝɾi dʒɛnɝəlz pɹɛzəns kʌmfɝɾɪd hɝ.

Siuan nodded. "Very well." She closed her eyes, and soon found herself blinking awake back in Bryne's tent. The candle was out, and she could hear Bryne breathing quietly from his pallet on the other side of the tent. She sat up and looked across at him, though it was too dark to see anything more than shadows. Strangely, after talking about Forsaken and Asha'man, the sturdy general's presence comforted her.

ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl tə ɹipɔɹt, ɛɡwin? sɪuən θɔɾ aɪdli, ɹaɪzɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ aʊɾ ə hɝ dʒɹɛs bɪhaɪn ðə skɹin ən pʊɾ ɑn əɹ slipɪŋ ɡaʊn. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ maɪt bi ɪn lʌv. ɪz ðət ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl ɪnʌf? tə hɝ, ɪt sim stʃɹeɪnʒɝ ðən ðə teɪn biɪŋ klɛnzd əɹ ə wʊmən tʃænəlɪŋ seɪɾɪn.

Is there anything else remarkable to report, Egwene? Siuan thought idly, rising to change out of her dress behind the screen and put on her sleeping gown. I think I might be in love. Is that remarkable enough? To her, it seemed stranger than the taint being cleansed or a woman channeling saidin.

ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ʃi tʌk ðə dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil bæk ɪn ɪts haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs, ðən snʌɡəl daʊn bɪniθ əɹ blæŋkəts.

Shaking her head, she tucked the dream ter'angreal back in its hiding place, then snuggled down beneath her blankets.

ʃid fɔɹɡoʊ ðə maɪs, dʒʌs ðɪs wʌns.

She'd forgo the mice, just this once.

tʃæptɝ naɪn

CHAPTER 9

livɪŋ mɔldən ə kul spɹɪŋ bɹiz tɪkəl pɛɹɪnz feɪs. sətʃ ə bɹiz ʃʊɾə kæɹid wɪð ɪt ðə sɛns ə pɑlən ən kɹɪsp mɔɹnɪŋ du, ʌv dɝɾ oʊvɝtɝn baɪ spɹaʊts pʊʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə laɪt, ʌv nu laɪf ən ən ɝθ ɹibɔɹn.

Leaving Malden A cool spring breeze tickled Perrin's face. Such a breeze should have carried with it the scents of pollen and crisp morning dew, of dirt overturned by sprouts pushing into the light, of new life and an earth reborn.

ðɪs bɹiz kæɹid wɪð ɪɾ oʊnli ðə sɛns ə blʌɾ ən dɛθ.

This breeze carried with it only the scents of blood and death.

pɛɹɪn tɝn ɪz bæk tə ðə bɹiz, nɛl daʊn ən ɪnspɛktɪd ðə wæɡənz wilz. ðə vihɪkəl wɑz ə stɝɾi kənstʃɹʌkʃən ə hɪkɝi, wʊd dɑɹkənd wɪð eɪdʒ. ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ɪn ɡʊd ɹɪpɛɹ, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd lɝn tə bi kɛɹfəl wən dilɪŋ wɪð ɪkwɪpmən fɹəm mɔldən. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪdn skɔɹn wæɡənz ən ɑksən əz ðeɪ dɪd hɔɹsəz, bʌt ðeɪ - laɪk ɔl il - bɪlivd ɪn tʃɹævlɪŋ laɪt. ðeɪ hædn meɪnteɪn ðə wæɡənz əɹ kɑɹts, ən pɛɹɪn hæd faʊn mɔɹ ðən wʌn hɪɾən flɔ dʊɹɪŋ ɪz ɪnspɛkʃən.

Perrin turned his back to the breeze, knelt down and inspected the wagon's wheels. The vehicle was a sturdy construction of hickory, wood darkened with age. It appeared to be in good repair, but Perrin had learned to be careful when dealing with equipment from Malden. The Shaido didn't scorn wagons and oxen as they did horses, but they - like all Aiel - believed in traveling light. They hadn't maintained the wagons or carts, and Perrin had found more than one hidden flaw during his inspection.

"nɛkst!" hi bɛloʊɾ əz i tʃɛk ðə fɝst wilz hʌb. ðə kɑmɛnt wɑz dɝɛktəɾ ət ðə kɹaʊɾ ə pipəl weɪɾɪŋ tə spik wɪð hɪm.

"Next!" he bellowed as he checked the first wheel's hub. The comment was directed at the crowd of people waiting to speak with him.

"maɪ lɔɹd," ə vɔɪs sɛd. ɪt wɑz dip ən ɹʌf, laɪk wʊd skɹeɪpɪŋ əɡɛnst wʊd. dʒɝɑɹɾ ɑɹɡændə, fɝs kæptən ʌv ɡildən. hɪz sɛnt wɑz ʌv wɛl-ɔɪld ɑɹmɝ. "aɪ mʌs pɹɛs ði ɪʃu ʌv əɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. əlaʊ mi tə ɹaɪɾ əhɛd wɪð əɹ mædʒəsti."

"My Lord," a voice said. It was deep and rough, like wood scraping against wood. Gerard Arganda, First Captain of Ghealdan. His scent was of well-oiled armor. "I must press the issue of our departure. Allow me to ride ahead with Her Majesty."

ðə "hɝ mædʒəsti" hi ɹəfɝd tə wɑz æliændɝ, kwin ʌv ɡildən. pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə wil; hi wɑzn əz fəmɪljɝ wɪð kɑɹpəntʃɹi əz i wɑz wɪð smɪθɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪz fɑðɝ hæd tɔɾ itʃ ə hɪz sʌnz tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz saɪnz ə tʃɹʌbəl ɪn ə wæɡən. bɛɾɝ tə fɪks ðə pɹɑbləm bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ðən tə bi stʃɹændəd hæfweɪ tə ðə dɛstəneɪʃən. pɛɹɪn ɹæn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz əkɹɔs ðə smuð, bɹaʊn hɪkɝi.

The "Her Majesty" he referred to was Alliandre, Queen of Ghealdan. Perrin continued working with the wheel; he wasn't as familiar with carpentry as he was with smithing, but his father had taught each of his sons to recognize signs of trouble in a wagon. Better to fix the problem before leaving than to be stranded halfway to the destination. Perrin ran his fingers across the smooth, brown hickory.

ðə ɡɹeɪn wɑz klɪɹli vɪzəbəl, ən i tɛstəd fəɹ kɹæks wɪð kwɛstɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz, sɝtʃɪŋ itʃ pɔɪn ə stʃɹɛs. ɔl fɔɹ wilz lʊkt ɡʊd.

The grain was clearly visible, and he tested for cracks with questing fingers, searching each point of stress. All four wheels looked good.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" ɑɹɡændə æskt.

"My Lord?" Arganda asked.

"wi ɔl mɑɹtʃ təɡɛðɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðæts maɪ ɔɹɾɝ, ɑɹɡændə. aɪ woʊn əv ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz θɪŋkɪŋ ðət wɝ əbændənɪŋ ðɛm."

"We all march together," Perrin said. "That's my order, Arganda. I won't have the refugees thinking that we're abandoning them."

ɹɛfjudʒiz. ðəɹ wɝ oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən ə ðoʊz tə kɛɹ fɔɹ. ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd! laɪt, ðət wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən lɪvd ɪn ði ɪntaɪɝ tu ɹɪvɝz. ən pɛɹɪn wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə fiɾɪŋ ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm. wæɡənz. mɛni mɛn dɪdn ʌndɝstæn ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ʌv ə ɡʊd wæɡən. hi leɪ daʊn ɑn ɪz bæk, pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə ɪnspɛk ði æksəlz, ən ðət ɡeɪv ɪm ə vju ʌv ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ, pɑɹʃəli blɑk baɪ mɔldənz nɪɹbaɪ sɪɾi wɔl.

Refugees. There were over a hundred thousand of those to care for. A hundred thousand! Light, that was far more than lived in the entire Two Rivers. And Perrin was in charge of feeding every one of them. Wagons. Many men didn't understand the importance of a good wagon. He lay down on his back, preparing to inspect the axles, and that gave him a view of the overcast sky, partially blocked by Malden's nearby city wall.

ðə sɪɾi wɑz lɑɹdʒ fəɹ wʌn ðɪs fɑɹ nɔɹθ ɪn ɔltɑɹə. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs mɔɹ ʌv ə fɔɹtʃɹəs ðən ə sɪɾi, wɪð dɔntɪŋ wɔlz ən taʊɝz. əntɪl ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, ðə læn ɝaʊn ðɪs sɪɾi hæd bɪn hoʊm tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ il, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn naʊ, mɛni kɪld, ʌðɝz flɛd, ðɛɹ kæptɪvz fɹid baɪ ən əlaɪəns bɪtwin pɛɹɪnz fɔɹsɪz ən ðə sintʃæn.

The city was large for one this far north in Altara. It was almost more of a fortress than a city, with daunting walls and towers. Until the day before, the land around this city had been home to the Shaido Aiel, but they were gone now, many killed, others fled, their captives freed by an alliance between Perrin's forces and the Seanchan.

ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd lɛft ɪm tu θɪŋz: ə sɛn ə blʌɾ ɑn ði ɛɹ ən ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən ɹɛfjudʒiz tə kɛɹ fɔɹ. ðoʊ hi wɑz hæpi tə ɡɪv əm ðɛɹ fɹiɾəm, hɪz ɡoʊl ɪn lɪbɝeɪɾɪŋ mɔldən hæd bɪn fɑɹ dɪfɹənt: ðə ɹɛskju ʌv feɪl.

The Shaido had left him two things: a scent of blood on the air and a hundred thousand refugees to care for. Though he was happy to give them their freedom, his goal in liberating Malden had been far different: the rescue of Faile.

ənʌðɝ il ɡɹup hæd bɪn ədvænsɪŋ ɑn ɪz pəzɪʃən, bʌt ðeɪd sloʊd, ðən kæmpt, ən wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹʌʃɪŋ təwɔɹd mɔldən. pɝhæps ðeɪd bɪn wɔɹn baɪ ʃeɪɾoʊ fliɪŋ ðə bæɾəl ðət ðeɪ hæɾ ə lɑɹdʒ ɑɹmi bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, wʌn ðət hæd dɪfiɾəd ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ tʃænlɝz. ɪt sim ðɪs nu ɡɹup bɪhaɪn pɛɹɪn hæɾ əz lɪɾəl dɪzaɪɝ tə ɛnɡeɪdʒ ɪm əz i hæd tə ɛnɡeɪdʒ ðɛm.

Another Aiel group had been advancing on his position, but they'd slowed, then camped, and were no longer rushing toward Malden. Perhaps they'd been warned by Shaido fleeing the battle that they had a large army before them, one that had defeated the Shaido despite their channelers. It seemed this new group behind Perrin had as little desire to engage him as he had to engage them.

ðət ɡeɪv ɪm taɪm. ə lɪɾəl bɪt, ət list.

That gave him time. A little bit, at least.

ɑɹɡændə wɑz stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ. ðə kæptən wɔɹ ɪz pɑlɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən hæɾ ɪz slɑɾɪd hɛlməɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm. ðə skwɑt mæn wɑzn ə pʌft-ʌp flʌf ʌv ən ɔfəsɝ, bʌɾ ə kɑmən mæn u hæd ɹɪzən θɹu ðə ɹæŋks. hi fɔt wɛl ən dɪɾ əz ɪnstʃɹʌktəd. juʒəwəli.

Arganda was still watching. The captain wore his polished breastplate and had his slotted helmet under his arm. The squat man wasn't a puffed-up fluff of an officer, but a common man who had risen through the ranks. He fought well and did as instructed. Usually.

"aɪm nɑt gɑnə bɛn ɑn ðɪs, ɑɹɡændə," pɛɹɪn sɛd, pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf əlɔŋ ðə dæmp ɡɹaʊn bɪniθ ðə wæɡən.

"I'm not going to bend on this, Arganda," Perrin said, pulling himself along the damp ground beneath the wagon.

"kʊd wi ət lis jus ɡeɪtweɪz ɪnstɛd?" ɑɹɡændə æskt, nilɪŋ daʊn, ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ - ʃɔɹn ʃɔɹt - nɪɹli bɹʌʃɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn əz i pikt ʌndɝ ðə wæɡən.

"Could we at least use gateways instead?" Arganda asked, kneeling down, graying hair - shorn short - nearly brushing the ground as he peeked under the wagon.

"ði æʃəmən ɑɹ nɪɹ dɛd fɹəm fətiɡ," pɛɹɪn snæpt. "ju noʊ ðæt."

"The Asha'man are near dead from fatigue," Perrin snapped. "You know that."

"ðeɪɹ tu taɪɝd fəɹ ə lɑɹdʒ ɡeɪtweɪ," ɑɹɡændə sɛd, "bʌt meɪbi ðeɪ kəd sɛn ə smɔl ɡɹup.

"They're too tired for a large gateway," Arganda said, "but maybe they could send a small group.

maɪ leɪɾi ɪz ɪɡzɔstəd fɹəm əɹ kæptɪvəɾi! ʃʊɹli jə doʊn min fəɹ əɹ tə mɑɹtʃ!"

My lady is exhausted from her captivity! Surely you don't mean for her to march!"

"ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz ɑɹ taɪɝd tu," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æliændɝ kən əv ə hɔɹs tə ɹaɪd, bʌt ʃiz livɪŋ wən ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs du. laɪt sɛn ðæts sun."

"The refugees are tired too," Perrin said. "Alliandre can have a horse to ride, but she's leaving when the rest of us do. Light send that's soon."

ɑɹɡændə saɪd, bʌt nɑɾəd. hi stʊɾ ʌp əz pɛɹɪn ɹæn fɪŋɡɝz əlɔŋ ði æksəl. hi kəd tɛl stʃɹɛs ɪn wʊd wɪð ə ɡlæns, bʌɾ i pɹəfɝd tʌtʃ. tʌtʃ wɑz mɔɹ ɹɪlaɪəbəl. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə kɹæk əɹ ə splɪntɝɪŋ wɛɹ wʊd wikənd, ən jə kəd fil ɪt nɪɹ tə bɹeɪkɪŋ. wʊd wɑz ɹɪlaɪəbəl laɪk ðæt.

Arganda sighed, but nodded. He stood up as Perrin ran fingers along the axle. He could tell stress in wood with a glance, but he preferred touch. Touch was more reliable. There was always a crack or a splintering where wood weakened, and you could feel it near to breaking. Wood was reliable like that.

ənlaɪk mɛn. ənlaɪk hɪmsɛlf.

Unlike men. Unlike himself.

hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. hi dɪdnt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt. hi hæd tə kip wɝkɪŋ, hæd tə kip duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə dɪstʃɹæk hɪmsɛlf. hi laɪk tə wɝk. hid bɪn ɡɪvən fɑɹ tu fju ɑpɝtunəɾiz fəɹ ɪt leɪtli. "nɛkst!" hi sɛd, vɔɪs ɛkoʊɪŋ əɡɛns ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə wæɡən.

He gritted his teeth. He didn't want to think about that. He had to keep working, had to keep doing something to distract himself. He liked to work. He'd been given far too few opportunities for it lately. "Next!" he said, voice echoing against the bottom of the wagon.

"maɪ lɔɹd, wi ʃəɾ ətæk!" ə bɔɪstɝəs vɔɪs dɪklɛɹd fɹəm bɪsaɪd ðə vihɪkəl.

"My Lord, we should attack!" a boisterous voice declared from beside the vehicle.

pɛɹɪn θʌmpt ɪz hɛd bæk əɡɛns ðə wɛl-tʃɹæmpəld ɡɹæs, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz. bɝteɪn ɡælɛn, lɔɹd kæptən ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, wɑz tə min wʌɾ ɑɹɡændə wɑz tə ɡildən. əsaɪd fɹəm ðət sɪŋɡəl sɪməlɛɹəɾi, ðə tu kæptənz wɝ əbaʊɾ əz dɪfɹən əz mɛn kəd bi. pɛɹɪn kəd si bɝteɪnz lɑɹdʒ, bjuɾəfli wɝk buts, wɪð klæsps ʃeɪp laɪk hɔks, fɹəm bɪniθ ðə wæɡən.

Perrin thumped his head back against the well-trampled grass, closing his eyes. Bertain Gallenne, Lord Captain of the Winged Guards, was to Mayene what Arganda was to Ghealdan. Aside from that single similarity, the two captains were about as different as men could be. Perrin could see Bertain's large, beautifully worked boots, with clasps shaped like hawks, from beneath the wagon.

"maɪ lɔɹd," bɝteɪn kəntɪnjud. "ə faɪn tʃɑɹdʒ fɹəm ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹd wəd skæɾɝ ðəɾ il ɹæbəl, ʌv ðɪs aɪm sɝɾən. waɪ, wi izəli dɛlt wɪð ði il hɪɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi!"

"My Lord," Bertain continued. "A fine charge from the Winged Guard would scatter that Aiel rabble, of this I'm certain. Why, we easily dealt with the Aiel here in the city!"

"wi hæd ðə sintʃæn, ðɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd, fɪnɪʃɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹɪɹ æksəl ən ɹɪəlɪŋ ɪz weɪ tə ðə fɹʌn tə tʃɛk ði ʌðɝ wʌn. hi wɔɹ ɪz oʊld, steɪn koʊt. feɪl wəd tʃæstaɪz ɪm fəɹ ðæt. hi wɑz səpoʊz tə pɹizɛn hɪmsɛlf əz ə lɔɹd. bʌt wəd ʃi ɹɪli ɪkspɛkt ɪm tə wɛɹ ə faɪn koʊɾ ɪf i wɑz gɑnə spɛn ən aʊɝ laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə mʌɾi ɡɹæs, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə bɑɾəmz ʌv wæɡənz?

"We had the Seanchan, then," Perrin said, finishing with the rear axle and wriggling his way to the front to check the other one. He wore his old, stained coat. Faile would chastise him for that. He was supposed to present himself as a lord. But would she really expect him to wear a fine coat if he was going to spend an hour lying in the muddy grass, looking at the bottoms of wagons?

feɪl wʊdnt wɑn ɪm tə bi ɪn ðə mʌɾi ɡɹæs ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, hæn ɑn ðə fɹʌn æksəl, θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ ɹeɪvən hɛɹ ən dɪstɪŋktɪv sɑldəiən noʊz. ʃi hɛl ðə sʌm toʊɾəl ə hɪz lʌv.

Faile wouldn't want him to be in the muddy grass in the first place. Perrin hesitated, hand on the front axle, thinking of her raven hair and distinctive Saldaean nose. She held the sum total of his love.

ʃi wɑz ɛvɹiθɪŋ tə hɪm.

She was everything to him.

hi hæd səksiɾəd - hid seɪv hɝ. soʊ waɪ dɪɾ i fil əz ɪf θɪŋz wɝ nɪɹli əz bæɾ əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn? hi ʃəd ɹɪdʒɔɪs, hi ʃəd bi ɛkstæɾɪk, ʃəd bi ɹɪlivd. hid wɝid soʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊɾ əɹ dʊɹɪŋ əɹ kæptɪvəɾi. ən jɛt naʊ, wɪð əɹ seɪfti sɪkjʊɹ, ɛvɹiθɪŋ stɪl fɛlt ɹɔŋ. sʌmhaʊ. ɪn weɪz i kʊdn ɪkspleɪn.

He had succeeded - he'd saved her. So why did he feel as if things were nearly as bad as they had been? He should rejoice, he should be ecstatic, should be relieved. He'd worried so much about her during her captivity. And yet now, with her safety secure, everything still felt wrong. Somehow. In ways he couldn't explain.

laɪt! wəd nʌθɪŋ dʒʌst wɝk əz ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə? hi ɹitʃt daʊn fəɹ ɪz pɑkət, wɑntɪŋ tə fɪŋɡɝ ðə nɑɾɪd kɔɹd hid wʌns kæɹid ðɛɹ. bʌt hid θɹoʊn ðəɾ əweɪ. stɑp ɪt! hi θɔt.

Light! Would nothing just work as it was supposed to? He reached down for his pocket, wanting to finger the knotted cord he'd once carried there. But he'd thrown that away. Stop it! he thought.

ʃiz bæk. wi kən ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə weɪ ɪt wɑz bɪfɔɹ. kænt wi?

She's back. We can go back to the way it was before. Can't we?

"jɛs, wɛl," bɝteɪn kəntɪnjud, "aɪ səpoʊz ðə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ə ðə sintʃæn kəd bi ə pɹɑbləm ɪn ən əsɔlt. bʌt ðəɾ il ɡɹup kæmpt aʊt ðəɹ ɪz smɔlɝ ðən wʌt wi ɔlɹɛɾi dɪfiɾəd. ən ɪf jə ɑɹ wɝid, jə kəd sɛnd wɝd tə ðət sintʃæn dʒɛnɝəl ən bɹɪŋ əɹ bæk. ʃʊɹli ʃi wəd wɪʃ tə faɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪɾ əs əɡɛn!"

"Yes, well," Bertain continued, "I suppose the departure of the Seanchan could be a problem in an assault. But that Aiel group camped out there is smaller than what we already defeated. And if you are worried, you could send word to that Seanchan general and bring her back. Surely she would wish to fight alongside us again!"

pɛɹɪn fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf bæk tə ðə moʊmənt. hɪz oʊn fulɪʃ pɹɑbləmz wɝ ɪɹɛləvənt; ɹaɪt naʊ, hi niɾəd tə ɡɛt ðiz wæɡənz muvɪŋ. ðə fɹʌn æksəl wɑz ɡʊd. hi tɝn ən pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝniθ ðə wæɡən.

Perrin forced himself back to the moment. His own foolish problems were irrelevant; right now, he needed to get these wagons moving. The front axle was good. He turned and pushed himself out from underneath the wagon.

bɝteɪn wɑz ə miɾiəm haɪt, ðoʊ ðə θɹi plumz ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ɪz hɛlmət meɪɾ ɪm lʊk tɔlɝ. hi hæɾ ɑn ɪz ɹɛɾ aɪ pætʃ - pɛɹɪn dɪdnt noʊ wɛɹ hid lɔs ði aɪ - ən ɪz ɑɹmɝ ɡlimd. hi simd ɪksaɪɾəd, əz ɪf i θɔt pɛɹɪnz saɪləns mɛn ðeɪ wəɾ ətæk.

Bertain was of medium height, though the three plumes rising from his helmet made him look taller. He had on his red eye patch - Perrin didn't know where he'd lost the eye - and his armor gleamed. He seemed excited, as if he thought Perrin's silence meant they would attack.

pɛɹɪn stʊd, dʌstɪŋ ɔf ɪz pleɪn bɹaʊn tʃɹaʊzɝz. "wɝ livɪŋ," hi sɛd, ðən hɛld ʌp ə hæn tə fɝbɪd fɝðɝ ɑɹɡjəmənt. "wi dɪfiɾəd ðə sɛps hɪɹ, bʌt wi hæɾ əm doʊzd wɪð fɔkɹuɾ ən ðəɹ wɝ deɪmeɪn ɑn əɹ saɪd. wɝ taɪɝd, wundəd, ən wɪv feɪl bæk. ðɛɹz noʊ fɝðɝ ɹizən tə faɪt. wi ɹʌn."

Perrin stood, dusting off his plain brown trousers. "We're leaving," he said, then held up a hand to forbid further argument. "We defeated the septs here, but we had them dosed with forkroot and there were damane on our side. We're tired, wounded, and we have Faile back. There's no further reason to fight. We run."

bɝteɪn dɪdn lʊk sæɾəsfaɪd, bʌɾ i nɑɾəd ən tɝn əweɪ, stɑmpɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə mʌɾi ɡɹaʊn təwɔɹd wɛɹ ɪz mɛn sæt ðɛɹ maʊns. pɛɹɪn lʊkt ət ðə smɔl ɡɹup ə pipəl u weɪɾəd ɪn ə klʌstɝ ɝaʊn ðə wæɡən tə spik wɪð hɪm. wʌns, ðɪs kaɪndə bɪznəs hæd fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd pɛɹɪn. ɪt sim laɪk pɔɪnləs wɝk, əz mɛni ʌv ðə sʌpləkəns ɔlɹɛɾi nu wʌɾ ɪz ænsɝ wəd bi.

Bertain didn't look satisfied, but he nodded and turned away, stomping across the muddy ground toward where his men sat their mounts. Perrin looked at the small group of people who waited in a cluster around the wagon to speak with him. Once, this kind of business had frustrated Perrin. It seemed like pointless work, as many of the supplicants already knew what his answer would be.

bʌt ðeɪ niɾəd tə hɪɹ ðoʊz ænsɝz fɹəm hɪm, ən pɛɹɪn hæd kʌm tə ʌndɝstæn ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə ðæt. bɪsaɪdz, ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz hɛlp dɪstʃɹækt ɪm fɹəm ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ tɛnʃən i fɛlt ət hævɪŋ ɹɛskjud feɪl.

But they needed to hear those answers from him, and Perrin had come to understand the importance of that. Besides, their questions helped distract him from the strange tension he felt at having rescued Faile.

hi wɔk təwɔɹd ðə nɛkst wæɡən ɪn laɪn, hɪz smɔl ɑntʊɹɑʒ fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm. ðəɹ wɝ ə ɡʊd fɪfti ʌv ðə wæɡənz sɛɾ ɪn ə lɔŋ kæɹəvæn tʃɹeɪn. ðə fɝst wʌnz wɝ loʊɾəd wɪð sælvədʒ fɹəm mɔldən;

He walked toward the next wagon in line, his small entourage following him. There were a good fifty of the wagons set in a long caravan train. The first ones were loaded with salvage from Malden;

ðə mɪɾəl wʌnz wɝ ɪn ðə pɹɑsɛs ə biɪŋ tʃɹiɾəd laɪkwaɪz, ən i hæɾ oʊnli tu lɛf tə ɪnspɛkt. hi hæd wɑntəd tə bi wɛl aʊɾ ə mɔldən bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt. ðət wəd pɹɑbli kæɹi hɪm fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ tə bi seɪf.

the middle ones were in the process of being treated likewise, and he had only two left to inspect. He had wanted to be well out of Malden before sunset. That would probably carry him far enough away to be safe.

ənlɛs ðiz nu ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡɪv tʃeɪs ɪn ɹivɛnʒ. wɪð ðə nʌmbɝ ə pipəl pɛɹɪn hæd tə muv, ə blaɪn mæn wəd bi eɪbəl tə tʃɹæk ðɛm.

Unless these new Shaido decided to give chase in revenge. With the number of people Perrin had to move, a blind man would be able to track them.

ðə sʌn dʒɹup təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən, ə ʃaɪnɪŋ spɑt bɪhaɪn ðə klaʊd kʌvɝ. laɪt, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə mɛs, wɪð ðə keɪɑs ʌv ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ ɹɛfjudʒiz ən sɛpɹəɾ ɑɹmi kæmps. ɡɛɾɪŋ əweɪ wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ði izi pɑɹt!

The sun drooped toward the horizon, a shining spot behind the cloud cover. Light, but this was a mess, with the chaos of organizing refugees and separate army camps. Getting away was supposed to be the easy part!

ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp wɑz ə dɪzæstɝ. hɪz pipəl hæd skævənʒd ən pæk mɛni ʌv ði əbændən tɛns. naʊ klɪɹd, ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi wɑz tʃɹæmpəld widz ən mʌd, lɪɾɝd wɪð ɹəfjuz. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, biɪŋ il, hæd pɹəfɝd tə kæmp aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɔlz, ɹæðɝ ðən wɪðɪn ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pipəl, noʊ dɪnaɪɪŋ ðæt. hu wəd spɝn ə naɪs bɛd, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ə bɛɾɝ mɪlətɛɹi pəzɪʃən, tə steɪ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn tɛns?

The Shaido camp was a disaster. His people had scavenged and packed many of the abandoned tents. Now cleared, the ground around the city was trampled weeds and mud, littered with refuse. The Shaido, being Aiel, had preferred to camp outside the city walls, rather than within them. They were a strange people, no denying that. Who would spurn a nice bed, not to mention a better military position, to stay outside in tents?

il dɪspaɪz sɪɾiz, ðoʊ. moʊst ə ðə bɪldɪŋz hæɾ iðɝ bɪn bɝn dʊɹɪŋ ði ɪnɪʃəl ʃeɪɾoʊ əsɔlt əɹ luɾəd fəɹ ɹɪtʃəz. dɔɹz biɾən daʊn, wɪndoʊz ʃæɾɝd, pəzɛʃənz əbændən ɑn ðə stʃɹits ən tʃɹæmpəl baɪ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹʌnɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ tə fɛtʃ wɔɾɝ.

Aiel despised cities, though. Most of the buildings had either been burned during the initial Shaido assault or looted for riches. Doors beaten down, windows shattered, possessions abandoned on the streets and trampled by gai'shain running back and forth to fetch water.

pipəl stɪl skɝiɾ əbaʊt laɪk ɪnsɛks, muvɪŋ θɹu ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts ən ɝaʊn ðə fɔɹmɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp, ɡɹæbɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ kəd tə stoʊ ɪt fəɹ tʃɹænspɔɹt. ðeɪɾ əv tə liv ðə wæɡənz bɪhaɪnd wʌns ðeɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹævəl - ɡɹeɪɾi kʊdn meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə pæs ə wæɡən θɹu - bʌt fəɹ naʊ, ðə vihɪkəlz wəd bi ə bɪɡ hɛlp. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlsoʊ ə ɡʊd nʌmbɝ ʌv ɑksən;

People still scurried about like insects, moving through the city gates and around the former Shaido camp, grabbing what they could to stow it for transport. They'd have to leave the wagons behind once they decided to Travel - Grady couldn't make a gateway big enough to pass a wagon through - but for now, the vehicles would be a big help. There were also a good number of oxen;

sʌmwʌn ɛls wɑz ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðoʊz, meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən ðeɪ wɝ fɪt tə pʊl ðə wæɡənz. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd lɛt mɛni ʌv ðə sɪɾiz hɔɹsəz ɹʌn ɔf. ə ʃeɪm, ðæt. bʌt jə meɪd jus ʌv wʌt jə hæd.

someone else was inspecting those, making certain they were fit to pull the wagons. The Shaido had let many of the city's horses run off. A shame, that. But you made use of what you had.

pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt ðə nɛkst wæɡən, bɪɡɪnɪŋ ɪz ɪnspɛkʃən wɪð ðə vihɪkəlz lɔŋ tʌŋ, tə wɪtʃ ɑksən wəd bi hɑɹnəst. "nɛkst!"

Perrin reached the next wagon, beginning his inspection with the vehicle's long tongue, to which oxen would be harnessed. "Next!"

"maɪ lɔɹd," sɛɾ ə skɹætʃi vɔɪs, "aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ aɪm nɛkst."

"My Lord," said a scratchy voice, "I believe that I am next."

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst oʊvɝ ət ðə spikɝ: sɛbæn beɪlwɝ, hɪz sɛkɹətɛɹi. ðə mæn hæɾ ə dʒɹaɪ, pɪntʃt feɪs ən ə pɝpɛtʃuəl stup ðət meɪɾ ɪm lʊk ɔlmoʊs laɪk ə ɹustɪŋ vʌltʃɝ. ðoʊ hɪz koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz wɝ klin, ɪt sim tə pɛɹɪn ðət ðeɪ ʃəd ʃɛd pʌfs ə dʌst itʃ taɪm beɪlwɝ stɛpt. hi smɛl mʌsti, laɪk ən oʊl bʊk.

Perrin glanced over at the speaker: Sebban Balwer, his secretary. The man had a dry, pinched face and a perpetual stoop that made him look almost like a roosting vulture. Though his coat and breeches were clean, it seemed to Perrin that they should shed puffs of dust each time Balwer stepped. He smelled musty, like an old book.

"beɪlwɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz oʊvɝ ðə tʌŋ, ðən tʃɛkɪŋ ðə hɑɹnəs stʃɹæps, "aɪ θɔt jə wɝ spikɪŋ wɪð ðə kæptɪvz."

"Balwer," Perrin said, running his fingers over the tongue, then checking the harness straps, "I thought you were speaking with the captives."

"aɪ hæv, ɪndid, bɪn bɪzi wɪð maɪ wɝk ðɛɹ," beɪlwɝ sɛd. "haʊɛvɝ, aɪ ɡɹu kjʊɹiəs. dɪd juv tə lɛt ðə sintʃæn teɪk ɔl ə ðə kæptɪv ʃeɪɾoʊ tʃænlɝz wɪð ðɛm?"

"I have, indeed, been busy with my work there," Balwer said. "However, I grew curious. Did you have to let the Seanchan take all of the captive Shaido channelers with them?"

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst ət ðə mʌsti sɛkɹətɛɹi. ðə waɪz wʌnz u kəd tʃænəl hæd bɪn nɑkt ʌnkɑnʃəs baɪ fɔkɹut; ðeɪd bɪn ɡɪvən oʊvɝ tə ðə sintʃæn waɪl stɪl ʌnkɑnʃəs, tə də wɪð əz ðeɪ plizd. ðə dɪsɪʒən hæd nɑt meɪd pɛɹɪn pɑpjəlɝ wɪð ði il əmʌŋ ɪz ælaɪz, bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv ðoʊz tʃænlɝz ɹʌnɪŋ əbaʊt tə teɪk ɹivɛnʒ ɑn hɪm.

Perrin glanced at the musty secretary. The Wise Ones who could channel had been knocked unconscious by forkroot; they'd been given over to the Seanchan while still unconscious, to do with as they pleased. The decision had not made Perrin popular with the Aiel among his allies, but he would not have those channelers running about to take revenge on him.

"aɪ doʊn si waɪ aɪ wəd wɑn ðɛm," hi sɛd tə beɪlwɝ.

"I don't see why I would want them," he said to Balwer.

"wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd, ðəɹ ɪz mʌtʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ ɪntʃɹəs tə lɝn. fəɹ ɪnstəns, ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðət mɛni ʌv ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɑɹ əʃeɪmd ə ðɛɹ klænz bɪheɪvjɝ. ðə waɪz wʌnz ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ əɾ ɑdz. ɔlsoʊ, ðeɪv hæd dilɪŋz wɪð səm vɛɹi kjʊɹiəs ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz u ɔfɝɾ əm ɑbʒɛkts ə paʊɝ fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. huɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ, ðeɪ kəd meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz."

"Well, my Lord, there is much of great interest to learn. For instance, it appears that many of the Shaido are ashamed of their clan's behavior. The Wise Ones themselves were at odds. Also, they have had dealings with some very curious individuals who offered them objects of power from the Age of Legends. Whoever they were, they could make gateways."

"fɔɹseɪkən," pɛɹɪn sɛd wɪð ə ʃɹʌɡ, stupɪŋ daʊn ɑn wʌn ni tə tʃɛk ðə ɹaɪt fɹʌnt wil. "aɪ daʊt wɪl fɪɡjɝ aʊt wɪtʃ wʌnz. pɹɑbli hæɾ ə dɪsɡaɪz ɑn."

"Forsaken," Perrin said with a shrug, stooping down on one knee to check the right front wheel. "I doubt we'll figure out which ones. Probably had a disguise on."

fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪz, hi sɔ beɪlwɝ pɝs ɪz lɪps ət ðət kɑmɛnt.

From the corner of his eyes, he saw Balwer purse his lips at that comment.

"ju dɪsəɡɹi?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"You disagree?" Perrin asked.

"noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd. "ði 'ɑbʒɛkts' ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ ɡɪvən ɑɹ vɛɹi səspɛkt, baɪ maɪ ɛstəmeɪʃən.

"No, my Lord," he said. "The 'objects' the Shaido were given are very suspect, by my estimation.

ði il wɝ dupt, ðoʊ fəɹ wʌt ɹizən, aɪ kænɑt jɛt fæðəm. haʊɛvɝ, ɪf wi hæd mɔɹ taɪm tə sɝtʃ ðə sɪɾi. . . ."

The Aiel were duped, though for what reason, I cannot yet fathom. However, if we had more time to search the city. . . ."

laɪt! wɑz ɛvɹi pɝsən ɪn ðə kæmp gɑnə æsk ɪm fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ nu ðeɪ kʊdn hæv? hi ɡɑt daʊn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn tə tʃɛk ðə bæk ə ðə wil hʌb. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt bɑðɝd hɪm. "wi ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ðət ðə fɔɹseɪkən əpoʊz ʌs, beɪlwɝ. ðeɪ woʊn ɹaɪtli wɛlkəm ɹænd ɪn wɪð oʊpən ɑɹmz tə sil əm əweɪ əɡɛn, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪts hiz ɡoʊɪŋ tə du."

Light! Was every person in the camp going to ask him for something they knew they couldn't have? He got down on the ground to check the back of the wheel hub. Something about it bothered him. "We already know that the Forsaken oppose us, Balwer. They won't rightly welcome Rand in with open arms to seal them away again, or whatever it is he's going to do."

blæstəd kʌlɝz, ʃoʊɪŋ ɹænd ɪn ɪz maɪnz aɪ! hi pʊʃt ðoʊz əweɪ əɡɛn. ðeɪ əpɪɹd wɛnɛvɝ i θɔɾ ə ɹænd əɹ mæt, bɹɪŋɪŋ vɪʒənz ə ðɛm.

Blasted colors, showing Rand in his mind's eye! He pushed those away again. They appeared whenever he thought of Rand or Mat, bringing visions of them.

"ɛniweɪ," pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud, "aɪ doʊn si wʌt jə nid mi tə du. wɪl teɪk ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɡeɪʃeɪn wɪð ʌs. ðə meɪɾənz kæptʃɝd ðɛɹ fɛɹ ʃɛɹ. jə kən ɪntɛɹəɡeɪt ðɛm. bʌt wɝ livɪŋ ðɪs pleɪs."

"Anyway," Perrin continued, "I don't see what you need me to do. We'll take the Shaido gai'shain with us. The Maidens captured their fair share. You can interrogate them. But we're leaving this place."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ sɛd. "ɪts dʒʌst ə ʃeɪm wi lɔs ðoʊz waɪz wʌnz. maɪ ɪkspɪɹiəns əz bɪn ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ ðoʊz əmʌŋ ði il wɪð ðə moʊst . . . ʌndɝstændɪŋ."

"Yes, my Lord," Balwer said. "It's just a shame we lost those Wise Ones. My experience has been that they are those among the Aiel with the most . . . understanding."

"ðə sintʃæn wɑntəd ðɛm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "soʊ ðeɪ ɡɑt ðɛm. aɪ wʊdn lɛɾ ɛdʒɹə bʊli mi ɑn ðə pɔɪnt, ən wʌɾ ɪz dʌn ɪz dʌn. wʌt dʒju ɪkspɛkt ə mi, beɪlwɝ?"

"The Seanchan wanted them," Perrin said. "So they got them. I wouldn't let Edarra bully me on the point, and what is done is done. What do you expect of me, Balwer?"

"pɝhæps ə mɛsədʒ kəd bi sɛnt," beɪlwɝ sɛd, "tə æsk səm kwɛstʃənz ə ðə waɪz wʌnz wən ðeɪ əweɪk. aɪ. . . ." hi stɑpt, ðən stup daʊn tə ɡlæns ət pɛɹɪn. "maɪ lɔɹd, ðɪs ɪz ɹæðɝ dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ. kʊdnt wi faɪn sʌmwʌn ɛls tə ɪnspɛk ðə wæɡənz?"

"Perhaps a message could be sent," Balwer said, "to ask some questions of the Wise Ones when they awake. I. . . ." He stopped, then stooped down to glance at Perrin. "My Lord, this is rather distracting. Couldn't we find someone else to inspect the wagons?"

"ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɪz iðɝ tu taɪɝɾ əɹ tu bɪzi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ wɑn moʊst ə ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə kæmps tə muv wən wi ɡɪv ðə mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ. ən moʊst ʌv əɹ soʊlʒɝz ɑɹ skævənʒəŋ ðə sɪɾi fəɹ səplaɪz - itʃ hændfʊl ʌv ɡɹeɪn ðeɪ faɪnd wɪl bi niɾəd. hæf ðə stʌfs spɔɪld ɛniweɪ. aɪ kæn hɛlp wɪð ðət wɝk, sɪns aɪ nid tə bi wɛɹ pipəl kən faɪn mi." hiɾ æksɛptɪd ðæt, kɹɔs ðoʊ ɪt meɪd hɪm.

"Everyone else is either too tired or too busy," Perrin said. "I want most of the refugees waiting in the camps to move when we give the marching order. And most of our soldiers are scavenging the city for supplies - each handful of grain they find will be needed. Half the stuff's spoiled anyway. I can't help with that work, since I need to be where people can find me." He'd accepted that, cross though it made him.

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ sɛd. "bʌt ʃʊɹli jə kən bi sʌmwɛɹ æksɛsəbəl wɪθaʊt kɹɔlɪŋ ʌndɝ wæɡənz."

"Yes, my Lord," Balwer said. "But surely you can be somewhere accessible without crawling under wagons."

"ɪts wɝk aɪ kən də waɪl pipəl tɔk tə mi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ju doʊnt nid maɪ hænz, dʒʌs maɪ tʌŋ. ən ðət tʌŋ ɪz tɛlɪŋ jə tə fɝɡɛt ði il."

"It's work I can do while people talk to me," Perrin said. "You don't need my hands, just my tongue. And that tongue is telling you to forget the Aiel."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"ðɛɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ aɪ kən du, beɪlwɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd fɝmli, ɡlænsɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm θɹu ðə spoʊks ə ðə wil. "wɝ hɛɾɪŋ nɔɹθ. aɪm dʌn wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ; ðeɪ kən bɝn fəɹ ɔl aɪ kɛɹ."

"There is nothing more I can do, Balwer," Perrin said firmly, glancing up at him through the spokes of the wheel. "We're heading north. I'm done with the Shaido; they can burn for all I care."

beɪlwɝ pɝst ɪz θɪn lɪps əɡɛn, ən i smɛl dʒʌst slaɪtli ʌv ənɔɪəns. "ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd, ɡɪvɪŋ ə kwɪk baʊ. ðən i wɪθdʒɹu.

Balwer pursed his thin lips again, and he smelled just slightly of annoyance. "Of course, my Lord," he said, giving a quick bow. Then he withdrew.

pɛɹɪn skwɝmd aʊɾ ən stʊɾ ʌp, nɑɾɪŋ tə ə jʌŋ wʊmən u stʊɾ ɪn ə dɝɾi dʒɹɛs ən wɔɹn ʃuz ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə laɪn ʌv wæɡənz. "ɡoʊ fɛtʃ lɪnkɑn," hi sɛd. "tɛl ɪm tə hæv ə lʊk ət ðɪs wil hʌb. aɪ θɪŋk ðə bɛɹɪŋz bɪn stʃɹɪpt, ən ðə blæstəd θɪŋ lʊks ɹɛɾi tə ɹoʊl ɹaɪɾ ɔf."

Perrin squirmed out and stood up, nodding to a young woman who stood in a dirty dress and worn shoes at the side of the line of wagons. "Go fetch Lyncon," he said. "Tell him to have a look at this wheel hub. I think the bearing's been stripped, and the blasted thing looks ready to roll right off."

ðə jʌŋ wʊmən nɑɾəd, ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ. lɪnkɑn wɑz ə mæstɝ kɑɹpəntɝ u hæd bɪn ənfɔɹtʃənəɾ ɪnʌf tə bi vɪzəɾɪŋ ɹɛləɾɪvz ɪn kɛɹhin wən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ətækt. hid hæd ðə wɪl biɾən nɪɹli aʊɾ ə hɪm. pɝhæps i ʃʊɾə bɪn ðə wʌn tə ɪnspɛk ðə wæɡənz, bʌt wɪð ðət hɔntəd lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪz, pɛɹɪn wɑznt ʃʊɹ haʊ fɑɹ i tʃɹʌstɪd ðə mæn tə də ə pɹɑpɝ ɪnspɛkʃən. hi simd ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf ət fɪksɪŋ pɹɑbləmz wən ðeɪ wɝ pɔɪntəɾ aʊt tə hɪm, ðoʊ.

The young woman nodded, running away. Lyncon was a master carpenter who had been unfortunate enough to be visiting relatives in Cairhien when the Shaido attacked. He'd had the will beaten nearly out of him. Perhaps he should have been the one to inspect the wagons, but with that haunted look in his eyes, Perrin wasn't sure how far he trusted the man to do a proper inspection. He seemed good enough at fixing problems when they were pointed out to him, though.

ən ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, əz lɔŋ əz pɛɹɪn kɛp muvɪŋ, hi fɛlt i wɑz duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, meɪkɪŋ pɹɑɡɹɛs. nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ʌðɝ ɪʃuz. wæɡənz wɝ izi tə fɪks. ðeɪ wɝn laɪk pipəl, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl.

And the truth was, as long as Perrin kept moving, he felt he was doing something, making progress. Not thinking about other issues. Wagons were easy to fix. They weren't like people, not at all.

pɛɹɪn tɝnd, ɡlænsɪŋ əkɹɔs ði ɛmpti kæmp, pɑkt wɪð faɪɹɛpɪts ən dɪskɑɹɾɪd ɹæɡz. feɪl wɑz wɔkɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾi; ʃid bɪn ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ səm ə hɝ fɑloʊɝz tə skaʊt ði ɛɹiə. ʃi wɑz stʃɹaɪkɪŋ. bjuɾəfəl. ðət bjuɾi wɑzn dʒʌst ɪn əɹ feɪs əɹ əɹ lin fɪɡjɝ, ɪt wɑz ɪn haʊ izəli ʃi kəmændəd pipəl, haʊ kwɪkli ʃi ɔlweɪz nu wʌt tə du. ʃi wɑz klɛvɝ ɪn ə weɪ pɛɹɪn nɛvɝ hæd bɪn.

Perrin turned, glancing across the empty camp, pocked with firepits and discarded rags. Faile was walking back toward the city; she'd been organizing some of her followers to scout the area. She was striking. Beautiful. That beauty wasn't just in her face or her lean figure, it was in how easily she commanded people, how quickly she always knew what to do. She was clever in a way Perrin never had been.

hi wɑzn stupəd; hi dʒʌs laɪk tə θɪŋk əbaʊt θɪŋz. bʌt hid nɛvɝ bɪn ɡʊd wɪð pipəl, nɑt laɪk mæt əɹ ɹænd. feɪl hæd ʃoʊn ɪm ðəɾ i dɪdnt nid tə bi ɡʊd wɪð pipəl, əɹ ivən wɪð wɪmən, əz lɔŋ əz i kəd meɪk wʌn pɝsən ʌndɝstæn hɪm. hi dɪdn əv tə bi ɡʊɾ ət tɔkɪŋ tə ɛniwʌn ɛls əz lɔŋ əz i kəd tɔk tə hɝ.

He wasn't stupid; he just liked to think about things. But he'd never been good with people, not like Mat or Rand. Faile had shown him that he didn't need to be good with people, or even with women, as long as he could make one person understand him. He didn't have to be good at talking to anyone else as long as he could talk to her.

bʌt naʊ hi kʊdn faɪn ðə wɝdz tə seɪ. hi wɝiɾ əbaʊt wʌt hæd hæpən tə hɝ dʊɹɪŋ əɹ kæptɪvəɾi, bʌt ðə pɑsəbɪləɾiz dɪdn bɑðɝ hɪm. ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪm æŋɡɹi, bʌt nʌn ʌv wʌt hæd hæpənd wɑz əɹ fɔlt. jə dɪd wʌt jə hæd tə tə sɝvaɪv. hi ɹɪspɛktɪɾ əɹ fəɹ əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ.

But now he couldn't find the words to say. He worried about what had happened to her during her captivity, but the possibilities didn't bother him. They made him angry, but none of what had happened was her fault. You did what you had to to survive. He respected her for her strength.

laɪt! hi θɔt. aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ əɡɛn! nid tə kip wɝkɪŋ. "nɛkst!" hi bɛloʊd, stupɪŋ daʊn tə kəntɪnju hɪz ɪnspɛkʃən ə ðə wæɡən.

Light! he thought. I'm thinking again! Need to keep working. "Next!" he bellowed, stooping down to continue his inspection of the wagon.

"ɪf aɪd sin jəɹ feɪs ən nʌθɪŋ ɛls, læd," ə hɑɹɾi vɔɪs sɛd, "aɪɾ əsum ðət wid lɔs ðɪs bæɾəl."

"If I'd seen your face and nothing else, lad," a hearty voice said, "I'd assume that we'd lost this battle."

pɛɹɪn tɝnd wɪð sɝpɹaɪz. hi hædn ɹilaɪz ðət tæm ælθɹ wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz weɪɾɪŋ tə spik wɪð hɪm. ðət kɹaʊd hæd θɪnd, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ stɪl səm mɛsənʒɝz ən ətɛndəns. ət ðə bæk, ðə blɑki, sɑləd ʃifɝɾɝ lin ɑn ɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf əz i weɪɾəd. hɪz hɛɹ hæɾ ɔl ɡɔn tə sɪlvɝ. pɛɹɪn kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ə taɪm wən ɪt hæd bɪn ə dip blæk. bæk wən pɛɹɪn hæd dʒʌs bɪn ə bɔɪ, bɪfɔɹ hid noʊn ə hæmɝ əɹ ə fɔɹdʒ.

Perrin turned with surprise. He hadn't realized that Tam al'Thor was one of those waiting to speak with him. That crowd had thinned, but there were still some messengers and attendants. At the back, the blocky, solid sheepherder leaned on his quarterstaff as he waited. His hair had all gone to silver. Perrin could remember a time when it had been a deep black. Back when Perrin had just been a boy, before he'd known a hammer or a forge.

pɛɹɪnz fɪŋɡɝz ɹitʃt daʊn, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə hæmɝ əɾ ɪz weɪst. hid tʃoʊzən ɪɾ oʊvɝ ði æks. ɪt hæd bɪn ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən, bʌt hid stɪl lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə bæɾəl fəɹ mɔldən. wɑz ðət wʌt bɑðɝd hɪm?

Perrin's fingers reached down, touching the hammer at his waist. He'd chosen it over the axe. It had been the right decision, but he'd still lost control of himself in the battle for Malden. Was that what bothered him?

əɹ wɑz ɪt haʊ mʌtʃ hiɾ ɛndʒɔɪd ðə kɪlɪŋ?

Or was it how much he'd enjoyed the killing?

"wʌt dʒju nid, tæm?" hi æskt.

"What do you need, Tam?" he asked.

"aɪm oʊnli bɹɪŋɪŋ ə ɹipɔɹt, maɪ lɔɹd," tæm sɛd. "ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɑɹ ɔɹɡənaɪz fəɹ ðə mɑɹtʃ, itʃ mæn wɪð tu tɛns ɑn ɪz bæk, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. wi kʊdn juz wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, ɑn əkaʊn ə ðə fɔkɹut, soʊ aɪ sɛn səm lædz tə ði ækwədʌk tə fɪl səm bæɹəlz ðɛɹ. wi kəd juz ə wæɡən tə bɹɪŋ əm bæk."

"I'm only bringing a report, my Lord," Tam said. "The Two Rivers men are organized for the march, each man with two tents on his back, just in case. We couldn't use water from the city, on account of the forkroot, so I sent some lads to the aqueduct to fill some barrels there. We could use a wagon to bring them back."

"dʌn," pɛɹɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. faɪnəli, sʌmwʌn u dɪd θɪŋz ðət wɝ niɾəd wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ tə æsk fɝst! "tɛl ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ðəɾ aɪ ɪntɛn tə hæv əm bæk hoʊm əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ðə moʊmənt ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild ɑɹ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðət kəd bi ə waɪl, ðoʊ."

"Done," Perrin said, smiling. Finally, someone who did things that were needed without having to ask first! "Tell the Two Rivers men that I intend to have them back home as soon as possible. The moment Grady and Neald are strong enough to make a gateway. That could be a while, though."

"ðæts əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd, maɪ lɔɹd," tæm sɛd. ɪt fɛl soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ fəɹ ɪm tə juz ə taɪɾəl. "kæn aɪ spik tə jə əloʊn fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðoʊ?"
