"That's appreciated, my Lord," Tam said. It felt so strange for him to use a title. "Can I speak to you alone for a moment, though?"

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðət lɪnkɑn wɑz kʌmɪŋ - hɪz lɪmp wɑz dɪstɪŋktɪv - tə lʊk ət ðə wæɡən.

Perrin nodded, noticing that Lyncon was coming - his limp was distinctive - to look at the wagon.

pɛɹɪn muvd wɪð tæm əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡɹup ʌv ətɛndəns ən ɡɑɹdz, wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv mɔldənz wɔl. mɔs ɡɹu ɡɹin əɡɛns ðə beɪs ə ðə mæsɪv blɑks meɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən; ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət ðə mɔs wɑz fɑɹ bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ðə tʃɹæmpəld, mʌɾid widz ʌndɝ ðɛɹ fit. nʌθɪŋ bʌt mɔs simd ɡɹin ðɪs spɹɪŋ.

Perrin moved with Tam away from the group of attendants and guards, walking into the shadow of Malden's wall. Moss grew green against the base of the massive blocks making up the fortification; it was strange that the moss was far brighter than the trampled, muddied weeds under their feet. Nothing but moss seemed green this spring.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt, tæm?" pɛɹɪn æskt əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ.

"What is it, Tam?" Perrin asked as soon as they were far enough away.

tæm ɹʌbd ɪz feɪs; ðəɹ wɑz ɡɹeɪ stʌbəl kʌmɪŋ ɪn. pɛɹɪn hæd pʊʃt ɪz mɛn hɑɹd ðiz læs fju deɪz, ən ðəɹ hædn bɪn taɪm fəɹ ʃeɪvɪŋ. tæm wɔɹ ə sɪmpəl blu wʊl koʊt, ən ðə θɪk klɔθ wɑz pɹɑbli ə wɛlkəm ʃild əɡɛns ðə maʊntən bɹiz.

Tam rubbed his face; there was gray stubble coming in. Perrin had pushed his men hard these last few days, and there hadn't been time for shaving. Tam wore a simple blue wool coat, and the thick cloth was probably a welcome shield against the mountain breeze.

"ðə lædz ɑɹ wʌndɝɪŋ, pɛɹɪn," tæm sɛd, ə lɪɾəl lɛs fɔɹməl naʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn. "dɪd jə min wʌt jə sɛɾ əbaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ɑn meɪnɛðɝən?"

"The lads are wondering, Perrin," Tam said, a little less formal now that they were alone. "Did you mean what you said about giving up on Manetheren?"

"aɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðæt bænɝ əz bɪn nʌθɪŋ bʌt tʃɹʌbəl sɪns ɪt fɝs keɪm aʊt. ðə sintʃæn, ən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, maɪɾ əz wɛl noʊ. ɪm noʊ kɪŋ."

"Aye," Perrin said. "That banner has been nothing but trouble since it first came out. The Seanchan, and everyone else, might as well know. I'm no king."

"ju hæv ə kwin huz swɔɹn jə əz əɹ lidʒ."

"You have a queen who's sworn you as her liege."

hi kənsɪɾɝd tæmz wɝdz, wɝkɪŋ aʊt ðə bɛst ɹɪspɑns. wʌns ðət kaɪndə bɪheɪvjɝ hæd meɪd pipəl θɪŋk i wɑz sloʊ ʌv θɔt. naʊ pipəl əsumd ɪz θɔtfəlnəs mɛn ðət pɛɹɪn wɑz kɹæfti ən kin maɪndəd. wʌɾ ə dɪfɝəns ə fju fænsi wɝdz ɪn fɹʌn ə jəɹ neɪm meɪd!

He considered Tam's words, working out the best response. Once that kind of behavior had made people think he was slow of thought. Now people assumed his thoughtfulness meant that Perrin was crafty and keen minded. What a difference a few fancy words in front of your name made!

"aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ ɹaɪt, ɪn wʌt jə dɪd," tæm sɛd, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli. "kɔlɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz meɪnɛðɝən wəd nɑɾ oʊnli hæv æntæɡənaɪz ðə sintʃæn, bʌt ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ hɝsɛlf. ɪt wəɾ ɪmplaɪ ðət jə mɛn tə hoʊl mɔɹ ðən dʒʌs ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ðət pɝhæps jə wɑntəd tə kɑŋkɝ ɔl ðət meɪnɛðɝən wʌns hɛld."

"I think you're right, in what you did," Tam said, surprisingly. "Calling the Two Rivers Manetheren would not only have antagonized the Seanchan, but the Queen of Andor herself. It would imply that you meant to hold more than just the Two Rivers, that perhaps you wanted to conquer all that Manetheren once held."

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ doʊn min tə kɑŋkɝ ɛniθɪŋ, tæm. laɪt! aɪ doʊn min tə hoʊld wʌt pipəl seɪ aɪv ɡɑt. ðə sunɝ ðəɾ ɪleɪn teɪks əɹ θɹoʊn ən sɛnz ə pɹɑpɝ lɔɹɾ aʊt tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ðə bɛɾɝ. wi kən bi dʌn wɪð ɔl ə ðɪs lɔɹd pɛɹɪn bɪznəs ən θɪŋz kən ɡoʊ bæk tə nɔɹməl."

Perrin shook his head. "I don't mean to conquer anything, Tam. Light! I don't mean to hold what people say I've got. The sooner that Elayne takes her throne and sends a proper lord out to the Two Rivers, the better. We can be done with all of this Lord Perrin business and things can go back to normal."

"æn kwin æliændɝ?" tæm æskt.

"And Queen Alliandre?" Tam asked.

"ʃi kən swɛɹ tə ɪleɪn ɪnstɛd," pɛɹɪn sɛd stʌbɝnli. "ɔɹ meɪbi dɝɛkli tə ɹænd. hi simz tə laɪk skupɪŋ ʌp kɪŋdəmz. laɪk ə tʃaɪl pleɪɪŋ ə ɡeɪm ʌv wɑbəlz."

"She can swear to Elayne instead," Perrin said stubbornly. "Or maybe directly to Rand. He seems to like scooping up kingdoms. Like a child playing a game of wobbles."

tæm smɛl kənsɝnd. tʃɹʌbəld. pɛɹɪn lʊkt əweɪ. θɪŋz ʃəd bi sɪmpəlɝ. ðeɪ ʃəd bi. "wʌt?"

Tam smelled concerned. Troubled. Perrin looked away. Things should be simpler. They should be. "What?"

"aɪ dʒʌs θɔt jə wɝ oʊvɝ ðɪs," tæm sɛd.

"I just thought you were over this," Tam said.

"nʌθɪŋ əz tʃeɪnʒd fɹəm ðə deɪz bɪfɔɹ feɪl wɑz teɪkən," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ stɪl doʊn laɪk ðət wʊlf hɛd bænɝ iðɝ. aɪ θɪŋk meɪbi ɪts taɪm tə teɪk ðət wʌn daʊn tu."

"Nothing has changed from the days before Faile was taken," Perrin said. "I still don't like that wolf head banner either. I think maybe it's time to take that one down too."

"ðə mɛn bɪliv ɪn ðət bænɝ, pɛɹɪn, læd," tæm sɛd kwaɪətli. hi hæɾ ə sɑft weɪ əbaʊt hɪm, bʌt ðət meɪd jə lɪsən wən i spoʊk. ʌv kɔɹs, hi ɔlsoʊ juʒəwəli spoʊk sɛns. "aɪ pʊl jə əsaɪd kəz aɪ wɑntəd tə wɔɹn ju. ɪf jə pɹəvaɪɾ ə tʃæns fəɹ ðə lædz tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, səm wɪl ɡoʊ. bʌt nɑt mɛni. aɪv hɝd moʊst swɛɹ ðət ðəl fɑloʊ jə tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ðeɪ noʊ ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz kʌmɪŋ - hu kʊdnt noʊ ðæt, wɪð ɔl ə ðə saɪnz leɪtli? ðeɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ænd niðɝ də aɪ, aɪ ɹɛkən." hi smɛld ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən.

"The men believe in that banner, Perrin, lad," Tam said quietly. He had a soft way about him, but that made you listen when he spoke. Of course, he also usually spoke sense. "I pulled you aside because I wanted to warn you. If you provide a chance for the lads to return to the Two Rivers, some will go. But not many. I've heard most swear that they'll follow you to Shayol Ghul. They know the Last Battle is coming - who couldn't know that, with all of the signs lately? They don't intend to be left behind." He hesitated. "And neither do I, I reckon." He smelled of determination.

"wil si," pɛɹɪn sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "wil si."

"We'll see," Perrin said, frowning. "We'll see."

hi sɛn tæm ɔf wɪð ɔɹɾɝz tə ɹɛkwəzɪʃən ə wæɡən ən teɪk ɪt fəɹ ðoʊz wɔɾɝ bæɹəlz. ðə soʊlʒɝz wəd lɪsən; tæm wɑz pɛɹɪnz fɝs kæptən, ðoʊ ðət sim bækwɝd tə pɛɹɪn. hi dɪdnt noʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə mænz pæst, bʌt tæm hæd fɔɾ ɪn ði il wɔɹ, lɔŋ əɡoʊ; hid hɛld ə sɔɹd bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn bɔɹn. ən naʊ hi fɑloʊd pɛɹɪnz ɔɹɾɝz.

He sent Tam off with orders to requisition a wagon and take it for those water barrels. The soldiers would listen; Tam was Perrin's First Captain, though that seemed backward to Perrin. He didn't know much of the man's past, but Tam had fought in the Aiel War, long ago; he'd held a sword before Perrin had been born. And now he followed Perrin's orders.

ðeɪ ɔl dɪd. ən ðeɪ wɑntəd tə kip duɪŋ soʊ! hædn ðeɪ lɝnd? hi ɹɛstəd bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, nɑt wɔkɪŋ bæk tə hɪz ətɛndəns, stændɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ.

They all did. And they wanted to keep doing so! Hadn't they learned? He rested back against the wall, not walking back to his attendants, standing in the shadow.

naʊ ðəɾ i sizd əpɑn ɪt, hi ɹilaɪz ðət wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt wɑz bɑðɝɪŋ hɪm. nɑt ðə hoʊl ʌv ɪt, bʌt sʌm, taɪɾ ɪn wɪð wʌt wɑz tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ hɪm. ivən naʊ ðət feɪl hæd ɹɪtɝnd.

Now that he seized upon it, he realized that was a part of what was bothering him. Not the whole of it, but some, tied in with what was troubling him. Even now that Faile had returned.

hi hædn bɪn ə ɡʊd liɾɝ leɪtli. hid nɛvɝ bɪn ə mɑɾəl wʌn, ʌv kɔɹs, nɑɾ ivən wən feɪl hæd bɪn ðəɹ tə ɡaɪd hɪm. bʌt dʊɹɪŋ əɹ æbsəns, hid bɪn wɝs. fɑɹ wɝs. hiɾ ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm ɹænd, ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɔl tə ɡɛɾ əɹ bæk.

He hadn't been a good leader lately. He'd never been a model one, of course, not even when Faile had been there to guide him. But during her absence, he'd been worse. Far worse. He'd ignored his orders from Rand, ignored everything, all to get her back.

bʌt wʌɾ ɛls wɑz ə mæn səpoʊz tə du? hɪz waɪf hæd bɪn kɪdnæpt!

But what else was a man supposed to do? His wife had been kidnapped!

hid seɪv hɝ. bʌɾ ɪn duɪŋ soʊ, hiɾ əbændən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. ən kəz ə hɪm, mɛn wɝ dɛd. ɡʊd mɛn. mɛn u hæd tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɪn hɪm.

He'd saved her. But in doing so, he'd abandoned everyone else. And because of him, men were dead. Good men. Men who had trusted in him.

stændɪŋ ɪn ðət ʃædoʊ, hi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ə moʊmənt - oʊnli ə deɪ pæst - wən ən ælaɪ hæd fɔlən tə il æɹoʊz, hɪz hɑɹt pɔɪzən baɪ mæsimə. ɛɹæm hæd bɪn ə fɹɛnd, wʌn ðət pɛɹɪn hæd dɪskɑɹɾɪd ɪn ɪz kwɛs tə seɪv feɪl. ɛɹæm hæd dɪzɝv bɛɾɝ.

Standing in that shadow, he remembered a moment - only a day past - when an ally had fallen to Aiel arrows, his heart poisoned by Masema. Aram had been a friend, one that Perrin had discarded in his quest to save Faile. Aram had deserved better.

aɪ ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛt ðət tɪŋkɝ pɪk ʌp ə sɔɹd, hi θɔt, bʌɾ i dɪdnt wɑnə dil wɪð ðɪs pɹɑbləm ɹaɪt naʊ. hi kʊdnt. ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ tə du. hi muvd əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɔl, plænɪŋ tə ɪnspɛk ðə læst wæɡən ɪn laɪn.

I should never have let that Tinker pick up a sword, he thought, but he didn't want to deal with this problem right now. He couldn't. There was too much to do. He moved away from the wall, planning to inspect the last wagon in line.

"nɛkst!" hi bɑɹkt əz i bɪɡæn əɡɛn.

"Next!" he barked as he began again.

ɝɑvin kɑɹnəl stɛp fɔɹwɝd. ði ɑmɑdɪʃən wʊmən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɔɹ əɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz;

Aravine Carnel stepped forward. The Amadician woman no longer wore her gai'shain robes;

ɪnstɛd ʃi hæɾ ɑn ə sɪmpəl laɪt ɡɹin dʒɹɛs, nɑt klin, ðət hæd bɪn pʊld aʊɾ ə ðə sælvədʒ. ʃi wɑz plʌmp bʌɾ əɹ feɪs stɪl bɔɹ ə hæɡɝd kæs fɹəm əɹ deɪz əz ə kæptɪv. ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən əbaʊt hɝ. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli ɡʊɾ əɾ ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, ən pɛɹɪn səspɛktəd ʃi wɑz ə noʊbəl hɛɹəɾədʒ. ʃi hæd ðə sɛn ʌv ɪɾ əbaʊt hɝ: sɛlf-kɑnfəɾəns, ən iz ɡɪvɪŋ kəmænz. ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ ðoʊz θɪŋz hæd sɝvaɪvd əɹ kæptɪvəɾi.

instead she had on a simple light green dress, not clean, that had been pulled out of the salvage. She was plump but her face still bore a haggard cast from her days as a captive. There was a determination about her. She was surprisingly good at organization, and Perrin suspected she was of noble heritage. She had the scent of it about her: self-confidence, an ease giving commands. It was a wonder those things had survived her captivity.

əz i nɛl daʊn tə lʊk ət ðə fɝst wil, hi fɪɡjɝɾ ɪt wɑz ɑd ðət feɪl hæd tʃoʊzən ɝɑvin tə supɝvaɪz ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz. waɪ nɑt wʌn ə ðə juðz fɹəm tʃɑ feɪl? ðoʊz dændiz kəd bi ənɔɪɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪd ʃoʊn ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ mɛʒɝ ə kɑmpəɾəns.

As he knelt down to look at the first wheel, he figured it was odd that Faile had chosen Aravine to supervise the refugees. Why not one of the youths from Cha Faile? Those dandies could be annoying, but they'd shown a surprising measure of competence.

"maɪ lɔɹd," ɝɑvin sɛd, hɝ pɹæktəs kɝtsi ənʌðɝ ɪndəkeɪʃən ə hɝ bækɡɹaʊnd. "aɪ hæv fɪnɪʃt ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ ðə pipəl fəɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ."

"My Lord," Aravine said, her practiced curtsy another indication of her background. "I have finished organizing the people for departure."

"soʊ sun?" pɛɹɪn æskt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə wil.

"So soon?" Perrin asked, looking up from the wheel.

"ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ dɪfəkəlt əz wi ɪkspɛktəd, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ kəmændəɾ əm tə ɡæðɝ baɪ næʃənæləɾi, ðən baɪ taʊn ə bɝθ. nɑt sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðə kɛɹhinɪn fɔɹm ðə lɑɹdʒəs bʌlk ə ðɛm, fɑloʊd baɪ ɔltɑɹənz, ðən ɑmɑdɪʃənz, wɪð səm smæɾɝɪŋ ʌv ʌðɝz. ə fju dəmɑni, səm tæɹɑbənɝz, ði əkeɪʒənəl bɔɹɾɝləndɝ əɹ tɛɹən."

"It was not so difficult as we expected, my Lord. I commanded them to gather by nationality, then by town of birth. Not surprisingly, the Cairhienin form the largest bulk of them, followed by Altarans, then Amadicians, with some smattering of others. A few Domani, some Taraboners, the occasional Borderlander or Tairen."

"haʊ mɛni kən stæn ə deɪ əɹ tu ʌv mɑɹtʃɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə wæɡənz?"

"How many can stand a day or two of marching without a ride in the wagons?"

"moʊst ə ðɛm, maɪ lɔɹd," ʃi sɛd. "ðə sɪk ən ɛldɝli wɝ ɪkspɛl fɹəm ðə sɪɾi wən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tʊk ɪt. ðə pipəl hɪɹ ɑɹ əkʌstəm tə biɪŋ wɝk hɑɹd. ðəɹ ɪɡzɔstəd, lɔɹd, bʌt nʌn tu iɡɝ tə bi weɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ wɪð ðoʊz ʌðɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp nɑt hæf ə deɪz mɑɹtʃ əweɪ."

"Most of them, my Lord," she said. "The sick and elderly were expelled from the city when the Shaido took it. The people here are accustomed to being worked hard. They're exhausted, Lord, but none too eager to be waiting here with those other Shaido camped not half a day's march away."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "stɑɹɾ əm mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪmiɾiətli."

"All right," Perrin said. "Start them marching immediately."

"ɪmiɾiətli?" ɝɑvin æskt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz.

"Immediately?" Aravine asked with surprise.

hi nɑɾəd. "aɪ wɑn əm ɑn ðət ɹoʊd, mɑɹtʃɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd, əz sun əz jə kən ɡɛɾ əm ɡoʊɪŋ. əl sɛn æliændɝ ən əɹ ɡɑɹd tə lid ðə weɪ." ðəɾ ɔt tə kip ɑɹɡændə fɹəm kəmpleɪnɪŋ, ən ɪt wəd ɡɛt ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. ðə meɪɾənz wəd bi fɑɹ bɛɾɝ, ən fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪfɪʃənt, ət ɡæðɝɪŋ səplaɪz əloʊn. ðə skævənʒəŋ wɑz nɪɹli fɪnɪʃt ɛniweɪ. hɪz pipəl wəɾ əv tə sɝvaɪv ɑn ðə ɹoʊd fəɹ oʊnli ə fju wiks. æftɝ ðæt, ðeɪ kəd dʒʌmp vaɪə ɡeɪtweɪ tə sʌmpleɪs mɔɹ sɪkjʊɹ. ændɝ, pɝhæps, əɹ kɛɹhin.

He nodded. "I want them on that road, marching northward, as soon as you can get them going. I'll send Alliandre and her guard to lead the way." That ought to keep Arganda from complaining, and it would get the refugees out of the way. The Maidens would be far better, and far more efficient, at gathering supplies alone. The scavenging was nearly finished anyway. His people would have to survive on the road for only a few weeks. After that, they could jump via gateway to someplace more secure. Andor, perhaps, or Cairhien.

ðoʊz ʃeɪɾoʊ bɪhaɪn hæɾ ɪm æŋkʃəs. ðeɪ kəd dɪsaɪd tə ətæk əɾ ɛni taɪm. bɛɾɝ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ ən ɹimuv ðə tɛmteɪʃən.

Those Shaido behind had him anxious. They could decide to attack at any time. Better to get away and remove the temptation.

ɝɑvin kɝtsiɾ ən hɝiɾ əweɪ tə meɪk pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz, ən pɛɹɪn θæŋk ðə laɪt fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls u dɪdn si ə nid tə kwɛstʃən əɹ sɛkənd-ɡɛs hɪm. hi sɛn ə bɔɪ tə ɪnfɔɹm ɑɹɡændə ʌv ði ɪmpɛndɪŋ mɑɹtʃ, ðən fɪnɪʃt ɪz ɪnspɛkʃən ə ðə wæɡən. æftɝ ðæt, hi stʊɾ ʌp, waɪpɪŋ ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz tʃɹaʊzɝz. "nɛkst!" hi sɛd.

Aravine curtsied and hurried away to make preparations, and Perrin thanked the Light for someone else who didn't see a need to question or second-guess him. He sent a boy to inform Arganda of the impending march, then finished his inspection of the wagon. After that, he stood up, wiping his hands on his trousers. "Next!" he said.

noʊbɑdi stɛp fɔɹwɝd. ði oʊnli pipəl ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪm wɝ ɡɑɹdz, mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪz ən ə fju wæɡənɪɹz weɪɾɪŋ tə hɪtʃ ʌp ðɛɹ ɑksən ən muv ðə wæɡənz ɔf fəɹ loʊɾɪŋ. ðə meɪɾənz hæd meɪɾ ə lɑɹdʒ paɪl ə fudstʌfs ən səplaɪz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə fɔɹmɝ kæmp, ən pɛɹɪn kəd meɪk aʊt feɪl ðəɹ wɝkɪŋ tə ɔɹɡənaɪz ɪt.

Nobody stepped forward. The only people remaining around him were guards, messenger boys and a few wagoneers waiting to hitch up their oxen and move the wagons off for loading. The Maidens had made a large pile of foodstuffs and supplies in the middle of the former camp, and Perrin could make out Faile there working to organize it.

pɛɹɪn sɛn ðə ɹɪŋ ʌv ətɛndəns wɪð ɪm oʊvɝ tə hɛlp hɝ, ðən faʊn hɪmsɛlf əloʊn. wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə du.

Perrin sent the ring of attendants with him over to help her, then found himself alone. With nothing to do.

dʒʌst wʌt hid wɑntəd tə əvɔɪd.

Just what he'd wanted to avoid.

ðə wɪn blu pæst əɡɛn, kæɹiɪŋ ðəɾ ɑfəl stɛntʃ ə dɛθ. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ kæɹid mɛmɹiz. ðə fjʊɹi ʌv ðə bæɾəl, ðə pæʃən ən θɹɪl ʌv itʃ swɪŋ. il wɝ ɛksələnt wɔɹiɝz - ðə bɛs ðə lænd nu. itʃ ɪkstʃeɪnʒ hæd bɪn kloʊz, ən pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɝn ɪz ʃɛɹ ə kʌts ən bɹuzəz, ðoʊ ðoʊz hæd sɪns bɪn hild.

The wind blew past again, carrying that awful stench of death. It also carried memories. The fury of the battle, the passion and thrill of each swing. Aiel were excellent warriors - the best the land knew. Each exchange had been close, and Perrin had earned his share of cuts and bruises, though those had since been Healed.

faɪɾɪŋ ði il hæd meɪɾ ɪm fil əlaɪv. itʃ wʌn hid sleɪn hæd bɪn ən ɛkspɝt wɪð ðə spɪɹz;

Fighting the Aiel had made him feel alive. Each one he'd slain had been an expert with the spears;

itʃ wʌn cʊɾə kɪl hɪm. bʌt hid wʌn. dʊɹɪŋ ðoʊz moʊməns ə faɪɾɪŋ, hid fɛlt ə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ pæʃən. ðə pæʃən ə faɪnəli duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. æftɝ tu mʌnθs ʌv weɪɾɪŋ, itʃ bloʊ hæd mɛn ə stɛp kloʊsɝ tə faɪndɪŋ feɪl.

each one could have killed him. But he'd won. During those moments of fighting, he'd felt a driving passion. The passion of finally doing something. After two months of waiting, each blow had meant a step closer to finding Faile.

noʊ mɔɹ tɔkɪŋ. noʊ mɔɹ plænɪŋ. hid faʊn pɝpəs. ən naʊ ɪt wɑz ɡɔn.

No more talking. No more planning. He'd found purpose. And now it was gone.

hi fɛl hɑloʊ. ɪt wɑz laɪk . . . laɪk ðə taɪm wən ɪz fɑðɝ hæd pɹɑməst ɪm sʌmθɪŋ spɛʃəl əz ə ɡɪft fəɹ wɪntɝnaɪt. pɛɹɪn hæd weɪɾəd mʌnθs, iɡɝ, duɪŋ ɪz tʃɔɹz tə ɝn ði ənnoʊn ɡɪft.

He felt hollow. It was like . . . like the time when his father had promised him something special as a gift for Winternight. Perrin had waited months, eager, doing his chores to earn the unknown gift.

wən hid faɪnəli ɹəsiv ðə smɔl wʊɾən hɔɹs, hid bɪn ɪksaɪɾəd fəɹ ə moʊmənt. bʌt ðə nɛks deɪ, hid bɪn ʃɑkɪŋli mɛlənkɑli. nɑt kəz ə ðə ɡɪft, bʌt kəz ðəɹ hæd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɪn ɛniθɪŋ tə stʃɹaɪv fɔɹ. ði ɪksaɪtmənt wɑz ɡɔn, ən oʊnli ðən hæɾ i ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ pɹɛʃəs hid faʊn ðəɾ æntɪsəpeɪʃən ðən ðə ɡɪft ɪtsɛlf.

When he'd finally received the small wooden horse, he'd been excited for a moment. But the next day, he'd been shockingly melancholy. Not because of the gift, but because there had no longer been anything to strive for. The excitement was gone, and only then had he realized how much more precious he'd found that anticipation than the gift itself.

sun æftɝ ðət hid bɪɡʌn vɪzəɾɪŋ mæstɝ luhənz fɔɹdʒ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli bɪkʌmɪŋ ɪz əpɹɛntəs.

Soon after that he'd begun visiting Master Luhhan's forge, eventually becoming his apprentice.

hi wɑz ɡlæd tə hæv feɪl bæk. hi ɹɪdʒɔɪst. ən jɛt, naʊ wʌt wɑz ðəɹ fəɹ hɪm? ðiz blæstəd mɛn sɔ hɪm əz ðɛɹ liɾɝ. səm ivən θɔɾ ə hɪm əz ðɛɹ kɪŋ! hid nɛvɝ æsk fəɹ ðæt. hid hæɾ əm pʊɾ əweɪ ðə bænɝz ɛvɹi taɪm ðeɪ pʊɾ əm aʊt, ʌp əntɪl feɪl hæd pɝsweɪɾəd ɪm ðət juzɪŋ əm wəd bi ən ædvæntɪdʒ. hi stɪl dɪdn bɪliv ðət ðə wʊlfhɛd bænɝ bɪlɔŋ ðɛɹ, flæpɪŋ ɪnsələnli əbʌv ɪz kæmp.

He was glad to have Faile back. He rejoiced. And yet, now what was there for him? These blasted men saw him as their leader. Some even thought of him as their king! He'd never asked for that. He'd had them put away the banners every time they put them out, up until Faile had persuaded him that using them would be an advantage. He still didn't believe that the wolfhead banner belonged there, flapping insolently above his camp.

bʌt kəɾ i teɪk ɪt daʊn? ðə mɛn dɪd lʊk tə ɪt. hi kəd smɛl pɹaɪɾ ɑn əm ɛvɹi taɪm ðeɪ pæst ɪt. hi kʊdn tɝn əm əweɪ. ɹænd wəd nid ðɛɹ eɪd - hid niɾ ɛvɹiwʌnz eɪd - ət ðə læs bæɾəl.

But could he take it down? The men did look to it. He could smell pride on them every time they passed it. He couldn't turn them away. Rand would need their aid - he'd need everyone's aid - at the Last Battle.

ðə læs bæɾəl. kəɾ ə mæn laɪk hɪm, ə mæn u dɪdnt wɑnə bi ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, lɛd ðiz fɔɹsɪz tə ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt moʊmən ɪn ðɛɹ laɪvz?

The Last Battle. Could a man like him, a man who didn't want to be in charge, lead these forces to the most important moment in their lives?

ðə kʌlɝz swɝld, ʃoʊɪŋ ɪm ɹænd, sɪɾɪŋ ɪn wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə stoʊn tɛɹən hoʊm.

The colors swirled, showing him Rand, sitting in what appeared to be a stone Tairen home.

pɛɹɪnz oʊl fɹɛn hæɾ ə dɑɹk kæs tə hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən, laɪk ə mæn tʃɹʌbəl baɪ weɪɾi θɔts. ivən sɪɾɪŋ laɪk ðæt, ɹænd lʊkt ɹiɡəl. hi wɑz wʌɾ ə kɪŋ wɑz səpoʊz tə bi, wɪð ðət ɹɪtʃ ɹɛd koʊt, ðət noʊbəl bɛɹɪŋ. pɛɹɪn wɑz dʒʌst ə blæksmɪθ.

Perrin's old friend had a dark cast to his expression, like a man troubled by weighty thoughts. Even sitting like that, Rand looked regal. He was what a king was supposed to be, with that rich red coat, that noble bearing. Perrin was just a blacksmith.

hi saɪd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən dɪspɛlɪŋ ði ɪmədʒ. hi niɾəd tə sik aʊt ɹænd. hi kəd fil sʌmθɪŋ tʌɡɪŋ ət hɪm, pʊlɪŋ hɪm.

He sighed, shaking his head and dispelling the image. He needed to seek out Rand. He could feel something tugging at him, pulling him.

ɹænd niɾəd hɪm. ðət hæd tə bi hɪz foʊkəs naʊ.

Rand needed him. That had to be his focus now.

tʃæptɝ tɛn

CHAPTER 10

ðə læst ə ðə təbæk ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi pʌf kwaɪətli ɑn ɪz paɪp, smoʊk kɝlɪŋ fɹəm ɪt laɪk ðə sɪnwəs kɔɪlz ʌv ə sneɪk.

The Last of the Tabac Rodel Ituralde puffed quietly on his pipe, smoke curling from it like the sinuous coils of a snake.

ðə smoʊk tɛnʒɹəlz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛmsɛlvz, pulɪŋ ət ðə silɪŋ əbʌv hɪm, ðən likɪŋ aʊt θɹu kɹæks ɪn ðə ɹuf ə ðə ɹæmʃækəl ʃɛd. ðə bɔɹdz ɪn ðə wɔlz wɝ wɔɹp fɹəm eɪdʒ, oʊpənɪŋ slɪts tə ði aʊtsaɪd, ən ðə ɡɹeɪ wʊd wɑz kɹækt ən splɪntɝɪŋ. ə bɹeɪziɝ bɝn ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ən wɪnz wɪsəl θɹu ðə kɹæks ɪn ðə wɔlz. ɪɾɝɑldi feɪnli wɝid ðoʊz wɪnz wəd bloʊ oʊvɝ ði ɪntaɪɝ bɪldɪŋ.

The smoke tendrils wrapped around themselves, pooling at the ceiling above him, then leaking out through cracks in the roof of the ramshackle shed. The boards in the walls were warped from age, opening slits to the outside, and the gray wood was cracked and splintering. A brazier burned in the corner and winds whistled through the cracks in the walls. Ituralde faintly worried those winds would blow over the entire building.

hi sæɾ ɑn ə stul, sɛvɹəl mæps ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə teɪbəl, hɪz təbæk paʊtʃ weɪd daʊn ə ɹɪŋkəl pis ə peɪpɝ. ðə smɔl skwɛɹ wɑz wɛðɝɾ ən foʊldəd fɹəm biɪŋ kæɹiɾ ɪn ɪz ɪnsaɪd koʊt pɑkət.

He sat on a stool, several maps on the table before him. At the corner of the table, his tabac pouch weighed down a wrinkled piece of paper. The small square was weathered and folded from being carried in his inside coat pocket.

"wɛl?" ɹədʒɑbi æskt. θɪk ə nɛk ən dɪtɝmən ʌv æɾətud, hi wɑz bɹaʊn-aɪd, wɪð ə waɪd noʊz ən ə bʌlbəs tʃɪn. hi wɑz kəmplitli bɔl naʊ, ən feɪnli ɹɪzɛmbəld ə lɑɹdʒ boʊldɝ. hi tɛndəd tə æk laɪk ə boʊldɝ, tu. ɪt kəd teɪk ə lɑɾ ʌv wɝk tə ɡɛɾ ɪm ɹoʊlɪŋ, bʌt wʌns jə dɪd, hi wɑz blʌɾi hɑɹd tə stɑp. hi hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə fɝs tə dʒɔɪn ɪɾɝɑldiz kɑz, fəɹ ɔl ðə fæk ðəɾ i hæd bɪn pɔɪz tə ɹəbɛl əɡɛns ðə kɪŋ dʒʌst ə ʃɔɹt taɪm bɪfɔɹ.

"Well?" Rajabi asked. Thick of neck and determined of attitude, he was brown-eyed, with a wide nose and a bulbous chin. He was completely bald now, and faintly resembled a large boulder. He tended to act like a boulder, too. It could take a lot of work to get him rolling, but once you did, he was bloody hard to stop. He had been one of the first to join Ituralde's cause, for all the fact that he had been poised to rebel against the king just a short time before.

ɪt hæd bɪn nɪɹli tu wiks sɪns ɪɾɝɑldiz vɪktɝi ət dɑɹlunə. hiɾ ɪkstɛndəd hɪmsɛlf fɑɹ fəɹ ðət vɪktɝi. pɝhæps tu fɑɹ. ɑ, ælsələm, hi θɔt. aɪ hoʊp ðɪs wɑz ɔl wɝθ ɪt, oʊl fɹɛnd. aɪ hoʊp jə hævən dʒʌst ɡɔn mæd. ɹədʒɑbi maɪt bi ə boʊldɝ, bʌt ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ ən ævəlæntʃ, ən wiv bɹɔɾ əm θʌndɝɪŋ daʊn əpɑn ʌs.

It had been nearly two weeks since Ituralde's victory at Darluna. He'd extended himself far for that victory. Perhaps too far. Ah, Alsalam, he thought. I hope this was all worth it, old friend. I hope you haven't just gone mad. Rajabi might be a boulder, but the Seanchan are an avalanche, and we've brought them thundering down upon us.

"wʌt naʊ?" ɹədʒɑbi pɹɑɾɪd.

"What now?" Rajabi prodded.

"wi weɪt," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. laɪt, bʌɾ i heɪɾəd weɪɾɪŋ. "ðɛn wi faɪt. əɹ meɪbi wi ɹʌn əɡɛn. aɪ hævən meɪɾ ʌp maɪ maɪn jɛt."

"We wait," Ituralde said. Light, but he hated waiting. "Then we fight. Or maybe we run again. I haven't made up my mind yet."

"ðə tæɹɑbənɝz - "

"The Taraboners - "

"woʊn kʌm," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd.

"Won't come," Ituralde said.

"ðeɪ pɹɑməst!"

"They promised!"

"ðeɪ dɪd." ɪɾɝɑldi hæd ɡɔn tə ðɛm hɪmsɛlf, hæd ɹaʊz ðɛm, hæɾ æskt əm tə faɪt ðə sintʃæn dʒʌst wʌn mɔɹ taɪm. ðeɪd jɛld ən tʃɪɹd, bʌt hæd nɑt fɑloʊd wɪð ɛni heɪst. ðeɪ wəd dʒɹæɡ ðɛɹ fit. hid ɡɑɾən əm tə faɪt "wʌn læs taɪm" ɑn hæf ə dʌzən dɪfɹən əkeɪʒənz naʊ. ðeɪ kəd si wɛɹ ðɪs wɔɹ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, ən i kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dɪpɛn ɑn ðɛm. ɪf hiɾ ɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs.

"They did." Ituralde had gone to them himself, had roused them, had asked them to fight the Seanchan just one more time. They'd yelled and cheered, but had not followed with any haste. They would drag their feet. He'd gotten them to fight "one last time" on half a dozen different occasions now. They could see where this war was going, and he could no longer depend on them. If he'd ever been able to in the first place.

"blʌɾi kaʊɝdz," ɹədʒɑbi mʌɾɝd. "laɪt bɝn ðɛm, ðɛn! wɪl də ɪɾ əloʊn. wɪv bɪfɔɹ."

"Bloody cowards," Rajabi muttered. "Light burn them, then! We'll do it alone. We have before."

ɪɾɝɑldi tʊk ə lɔŋ, kəntɛmpləɾɪv pʌf ɑn ɪz paɪp. hid tʃoʊzən tə faɪnəli juz ðə tu ɹɪvɝz təbæk. ðɪs paɪpfəl wɑz ðə læst ɪn ɪz stɔɹ; hid bɪn seɪvɪŋ ɪt fəɹ mʌnθs, naʊ. ɡʊd fleɪvɝ. bɛs ðəɹ wɑz.

Ituralde took a long, contemplative puff on his pipe. He'd chosen to finally use the Two Rivers tabac. This pipeful was the last in his store; he'd been saving it for months, now. Good flavor. Best there was.

hi stʌɾid ɪz mæps əɡɛn, hoʊldɪŋ ə smɔlɝ wʌn ʌp bɪfɔɹ hɪm. hi kəd juz bɛɾɝ mæps, ðət wɑz sɝɾən. "ðɪs nu sintʃæn dʒɛnɝəl," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, "ɪz mɑɹʃəlɪŋ oʊvɝ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən mɛn, wɪð ə ɡʊd tu hʌnʒɹəd deɪmeɪn."

He studied his maps again, holding a smaller one up before him. He could use better maps, that was certain. "This new Seanchan general," Ituralde said, "is marshaling over three hundred thousand men, with a good two hundred damane."

"wiv bit lɑɹdʒ fɔɹsɪz bɪfɔɹ. lʊk wʌt wi dɪɾ ət dɑɹlunə! jə kɹʌʃt ðɛm, ɹoʊɾəl!"

"We've beat large forces before. Look what we did at Darluna! You crushed them, Rodel!"

ən duɪŋ soʊ hæd ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɛvɹi bɪɾ ə kɹæftinəs, skɪl ən lʌk ɪɾɝɑldi kəd mʌstɝ. ivən ðɛn, hid lɔst wɛl oʊvɝ hæf ɪz mɛn. naʊ hi ɹæn, lɪmpɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ ðɪs sɛkənd, lɑɹdʒɝ fɔɹs ə sintʃæn.

And doing so had required every bit of craftiness, skill and luck Ituralde could muster. Even then, he'd lost well over half his men. Now he ran, limping, before this second, larger force of Seanchan.

ðɪs taɪm, ðeɪ wɝn meɪkɪŋ ɛni mɪsteɪks. ðə sintʃæn dɪdn ɹɪlaɪ soʊlli ɑn ðɛɹ ɹeɪkən. hɪz mɛn hæɾ ɪntɝsɛptəd sɛvɹəl fʊt skaʊts, ən ðət mɛn dʌzənz hædn bɪn kɑt. ðɪs taɪm, ðə sintʃæn nu ɪɾɝɑldiz tʃɹu nʌmbɝz ən ɪz tʃɹu loʊkeɪʃən.

This time, they weren't making any mistakes. The Seanchan didn't rely solely on their raken. His men had intercepted several foot scouts, and that meant dozens hadn't been caught. This time, the Seanchan knew Ituralde's true numbers and his true location.

hɪz ɛnəmiz wɝ dʌn biɪŋ hɝɾɪd ən ɡoʊɾɪd; ɪnstɛd ðeɪ hʌntəd hɪm, ɹɪlɛnləsli, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɪz tʃɹæps. ɪɾɝɑldi hæd plæn tə ɹitʃɹit dipɝ ən dipɝ ɪndə ɑɹæd dumən; ðət wəd feɪvɝ ɪz fɔɹsɪz ən stʃɹɛtʃ ðə sintʃæn səplaɪ laɪnz. hid fɪɡjɝɾ i kəd kip ɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ənʌðɝ fɔɹ əɹ faɪv mʌnθs. bʌt ðoʊz plænz wɝ jusləs naʊ; ðeɪd bɪn meɪd bɪfɔɹ ɪɾɝɑldi hæd dɪskʌvɝd ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪntaɪɝ blʌɾi ɑɹmi ʌv il ɹʌnɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɑɹæd dumən. ɪf ðə ɹɪpɔɹts wɝ tə bi bɪlivd -  ən ɹɪpɔɹts əbaʊɾ il wɝ ɔfən ɪɡzædʒɝeɪʃənz, soʊ hi wɑznt ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ tə bɪliv - ðəɹ wɝ ʌpwɝdz ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən ə ðɛm hoʊldɪŋ lɑɹdʒ sɛkʃənz ə ðə nɔɹθ, bændɑɹ ɛbən ɪnkluɾəd.

His enemies were done being herded and goaded; instead they hunted him, relentlessly, avoiding his traps. Ituralde had planned to retreat deeper and deeper into Arad Doman; that would favor his forces and stretch the Seanchan supply lines. He'd figured he could keep it up for another four or five months. But those plans were useless now; they'd been made before Ituralde had discovered there was an entire bloody army of Aiel running about Arad Doman. If the reports were to be believed -  and reports about Aiel were often exaggerations, so he wasn't sure how much to believe - there were upwards of a hundred thousand of them holding large sections of the north, Bandar Eban included.

ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən il. ðət wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz tu hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən dəmɑni tʃɹups. pɝhæps mɔɹ. ɪɾɝɑldi wɛl ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə blʌd snoʊ twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ, wən ɪt hæd sim hid lɔs tɛn mɛn fəɹ itʃ il u fɛl.

A hundred thousand Aiel. That was as good as two hundred thousand Domani troops. Perhaps more. Ituralde well remembered the Blood Snow twenty years ago, when it had seemed he'd lost ten men for each Aiel who fell.

hi wɑz tʃɹæpt, ə wɔlnʌt kɹʌʃt bɪtwin tu stoʊnz. ðə bɛs hid bɪn eɪbəl tə də wɑz ɹitʃɹit hɪɹ, tə ðɪs əbændən stɛɾɪŋ. ðət wəd ɡɪv ɪm ən ɛdʒ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn. bʌɾ oʊnli ə smɔl wʌn. ðə sintʃæn hæɾ ə fɔɹs sɪks taɪmz ðə saɪz ə hɪz oʊn, ən ðə ɡɹinəst ə kəmændɝz nu ðət faɪɾɪŋ ðoʊz ɑdz wɑz suəsaɪd.

He was trapped, a walnut crushed between two stones. The best he'd been able to do was retreat here, to this abandoned stedding. That would give him an edge against the Seanchan. But only a small one. The Seanchan had a force six times the size of his own, and the greenest of commanders knew that fighting those odds was suicide.

"hæv jə ɛvɝ sin ə mæstɝ dʒʌɡəlɝ, ɹədʒɑbi?" ɪɾɝɑldi æskt, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə mæp.

"Have you ever seen a master juggler, Rajabi?" Ituralde asked, studying the map.

fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, ɪɾɝɑldi sɔ ðə bʊl-laɪk mæn fɹaʊn ɪn kənfjuʒən. "aɪv sin ɡlimən u - "

From the corner of his eye, Ituralde saw the bull-like man frown in confusion. "I've seen gleemen who - "

"noʊ, nɑɾ ə ɡlimən. ə mæstɝ."

"No, not a gleeman. A master."

ɹədʒɑbi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

Rajabi shook his head.

ɪɾɝɑldi pʌft ɪn θɔt bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. "aɪ dɪd, wʌns. hi wɑz ðə kɔɹt bɑɹɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn. spɹaɪ fɛloʊ, wɪð ə wɪt ðət maɪt bɛɾɝ əv bɪlɔŋd ɪn ə kɑmən ɹum, fəɹ ɔl ðə weɪ hi wɑz dɛkɝeɪɾəd. bɑɹdz doʊn ɔfən dʒʌɡəl; bʌt ðɪs fɛloʊ dɪdn maɪn ðə ɹɪkwɛst. hi laɪk dʒʌɡəlɪŋ tə pliz ðə jʌŋ dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, soʊ aɪ ʌndɝstænd."

Ituralde puffed in thought before speaking. "I did, once. He was the court bard of Caemlyn. Spry fellow, with a wit that might better have belonged in a common room, for all the way he was decorated. Bards don't often juggle; but this fellow didn't mind the request. He liked juggling to please the young Daughter-Heir, so I understand."

hi ɹimuv ðə paɪp fɹəm ɪz maʊθ, tæpɪŋ daʊn ðə təbæk.

He removed the pipe from his mouth, tapping down the tabac.

"ɹoʊɾəl," ɹədʒɑbi sɛd. "ðə sintʃæn. . . ."

"Rodel," Rajabi said. "The Seanchan. . . ."

ɹoʊɾəl hɛld ʌp ə fɪŋɡɝ, sɪtʃuweɪɾɪŋ ɪz paɪp bɪfɔɹ kəntɪnjuɪŋ. "ðə bɑɹd stɑɹɾəd baɪ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ θɹi bɔlz. ðən i æskt əs ɪf wi θɔɾ i kəd də ənʌðɝ. wi tʃɪɹɾ ɪm ɑn. hi wɛn tə fɔɹ, ðən faɪv, ðən sɪks. wɪð itʃ bɔl i æɾəd, əɹ əplɔz ɡɹu ɡɹeɪɾɝ, ən i ɔlweɪz æskt ɪf wi θɔɾ i kəd də ənʌðɝ. ʌv kɔɹs wi sɛd jɛs.

Rodel held up a finger, situating his pipe before continuing. "The bard started by juggling three balls. Then he asked us if we thought he could do another. We cheered him on. He went to four, then five, then six. With each ball he added, our applause grew greater, and he always asked if we thought he could do another. Of course we said yes.

"sɛvən, eɪt, naɪn. sun i hæd tɛn bɔlz ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, flaɪɪŋ ɪn ə pæɾɝn soʊ kɑmplɛks ðəɾ aɪ kʊdn tʃɹæk ðɛm. hi hæd tə stʃɹeɪn tə kip əm ɡoʊɪŋ; hi kɛp hævɪŋ tə ɹitʃ daʊn ən ɡɹæb bɔlz ðəɾ i nɪɹli mɪst. hi wɑz tu lɔst ɪn kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən tə æsk əs ɪf i ʃəɾ æɾ ənʌðɝ, bʌt ðə kɹaʊd kɔl fəɹ ɪt. ɪlɛvən! ɡoʊ fəɹ ɪlɛvən! ən soʊ, hɪz əsɪstən tɔst ənʌðɝ bɔl ɪndə ðə mɛs."

"Seven, eight, nine. Soon he had ten balls going in the air, flying in a pattern so complex that I couldn't track them. He had to strain to keep them going; he kept having to reach down and grab balls that he nearly missed. He was too lost in concentration to ask us if he should add another, but the crowd called for it. Eleven! Go for eleven! And so, his assistant tossed another ball into the mess."

ɪɾɝɑldi pʌft.

Ituralde puffed.

"hi dʒɹɑp ðɛm?" ɹədʒɑbi æskt.

"He dropped them?" Rajabi asked.

ɹoʊɾəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðæt læst 'bɔl' wɑzn æktʃəli  ə bɔl əɾ ɔl. ɪt wɑz kaɪndə ʌv ɪluməneɪɾɝz tʃɹɪk; wʌns ɪt ɡɑt hæfweɪ tə ðə bɑɹd, ɪt flæʃt ən ɡeɪv ɔf ə sʌɾən bɝst ə laɪɾ ən smoʊk. baɪ ðə taɪm əɹ vɪʒən klɪɹd, ðə bɑɹd wɑz ɡɔn, ən tɛn bɔlz wɝ laɪn ʌp ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

Rodel shook his head. "That last 'ball' wasn't actually a ball at all. It was some kind of Illuminator's trick; once it got halfway to the bard, it flashed and gave off a sudden burst of light and smoke. By the time our vision cleared, the bard was gone, and ten balls were lined up on the floor.

wən aɪ lʊkt ɝaʊnd, aɪ faʊn ɪm sɪɾɪŋ ət wʌn ə ðə teɪbəlz wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə daɪnɝz, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ə kʌp ʌv waɪn ən flɝɾɪŋ wɪð lɔɹd fɪndəlz waɪf."

When I looked around, I found him sitting at one of the tables with the rest of the diners, drinking a cup of wine and flirting with Lord Finndal's wife."

pʊɹ ɹədʒɑbi lʊkt kəmplitli dʌmfaʊndɪd. hi laɪkt ɪz ænsɝz niɾ ən stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd.

Poor Rajabi looked completely dumbfounded. He liked his answers neat and straightforward.

ɪɾɝɑldi juʒəwəli fɛl ðə seɪm weɪ, bʌt ðiz deɪz - wɪð ðɛɹ ənnətʃɝəli oʊvɝkæst skaɪz ən sɛns ə pɝpɛtʃuəl ɡlum - meɪɾ ɪm fɪləsɑfɪk.

Ituralde usually felt the same way, but these days - with their unnaturally overcast skies and sense of perpetual gloom - made him philosophic.

hi ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən tʊk ðə wɔɹn, foʊldəd ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ ɔf ðə teɪbəl fɹəm bɪniθ ɪz təbæk paʊtʃ. hi hændəɾ ɪt tə ɹədʒɑbi.

He reached out and took the worn, folded sheet of paper off the table from beneath his tabac pouch. He handed it to Rajabi.

" 'stʃɹaɪk hɑɹɾ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn,' " ɹədʒɑbi ɹɛd. " 'pʊʃ əm əweɪ, fɔɹs əm ɪndə ðɛɹ boʊts ən bæk əkɹɔs ðɛɹ blʌɾi oʊʃən. aɪm kaʊntɪŋ ɑn ju, oʊl fɹɛnd. kɪŋ ælsələm.' " ɹədʒɑbi loʊɝd ðə lɛɾɝ. "aɪ noʊ ʌv ɪz ɔɹɾɝz, ɹoʊɾəl. aɪ dɪdn kʌm ɪndə ðɪs kəz ə hɪm. aɪ keɪm kəz ə ju."

" 'Strike hard against the Seanchan,' " Rajabi read. " 'Push them away, force them into their boats and back across their bloody ocean. I'm counting on you, old friend. King Alsalam.' " Rajabi lowered the letter. "I know of his orders, Rodel. I didn't come into this because of him. I came because of you."

"jɛs, bʌɾ aɪ faɪt kəz ə hɪm," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. hi wɑz ə kɪŋz mæn; hi ɔlweɪz wəd bi. hi stʊɾ ʌp, tæpɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz təbæk ən ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ði ɛmbɝz bɪniθ ðə hil ə hɪz but. hi sɛt ðə paɪp əsaɪɾ ən tʊk ðə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ɹədʒɑbi, ðən wɔk tə ðə dɔɹ.

"Yes, but I fight because of him," Ituralde said. He was a king's man; he always would be. He stood up, tapping out his tabac and grinding the embers beneath the heel of his boot. He set the pipe aside and took the letter from Rajabi, then walked to the door.

hi niɾəd tə meɪk ə dɪsɪʒən. steɪ ən faɪt, əɹ fli fəɹ ə wɝs loʊkeɪʃən, bʌt ɡeɪn ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ taɪm?

He needed to make a decision. Stay and fight, or flee for a worse location, but gain a little more time?

ðə ʃæk ɡɹoʊn ən wɪnd ʃʊk ðə tʃɹiz əz ɪɾɝɑldi stɛpt aʊtsaɪɾ ɪndə ði oʊvɝkæs mɔɹnɪŋ.

The shack groaned and wind shook the trees as Ituralde stepped outside into the overcast morning.

ðə ʃɛd wɑzn oʊɡiɝ-bɪlt, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪt wɑz tu flɪmzi fəɹ ðæt. ðɪs stɛɾɪŋ hæd bɪn əbændən fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm. hɪz mɛn kæmpt əmɪd ðə tʃɹiz. hɑɹdli ðə bɛs loʊkeɪʃən fəɹ ə wɔɹ kæmp, bʌt wʌn meɪd sup wɪð ðə spaɪsəz ɑn hænd; ðə stɛɾɪŋ wɑz fɑɹ tu jusfəl tə pæs ʌp. ənʌðɝ mæn maɪɾ əv flɛd tə ə sɪɾi ən hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ɪts wɔlz, bʌt hɪɹ ɪn ðiz tʃɹiz, ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz jusləs.

The shed wasn't Ogier-built, of course. It was too flimsy for that. This stedding had been abandoned for a long time. His men camped amid the trees. Hardly the best location for a war camp, but one made soup with the spices on hand; the stedding was far too useful to pass up. Another man might have fled to a city and hidden behind its walls, but here in these trees, the One Power was useless.

nɪɡeɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn deɪmeɪn wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən wɔlz, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ haɪ.

Negating the Seanchan damane was better than walls, no matter how high.

wɪv tə steɪ, ɪɾɝɑldi θɔt, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪz mɛn wɝk, dɪɡɪŋ ɪn, ɪɹɛktɪŋ ə pælɪsɑd. hi heɪɾəd ðə θɔɾ ə kʌɾɪŋ daʊn tʃɹiz ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ. hid noʊn ə fju oʊɡiɝ ɪn ɪz taɪm, ən ɹɪspɛktɪd ðɛm. ðiz mæsɪv oʊks pɹɑbli hɛl səm lɪŋɡɝɪŋ stʃɹɛŋkθ fɹəm ðə deɪz wən ði oʊɡiɝ hæd lɪv hɪɹ. kʌɾɪŋ əm daʊn wɑz ə kɹaɪm. bʌt jə dɪd wʌt jə hæd tə. ɹʌnɪŋ maɪt ɡeɪn ɪm mɔɹ taɪm, bʌɾ ɪt maɪt dʒʌst əz izəli luz ɪm taɪm. hi hæɾ ə fju deɪz hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn hɪt hɪm. ɪf i kəd dɪɡ ɪn wɛl, hi maɪt fɔɹs əm ɪndə ə sidʒ. ðə stɛɾɪŋ wəd meɪk əm hɛzɪɾənt, ən ðə fɔɹəsts wəd wɝk tə ði ædvæntɪdʒ ʌv ɪɾɝɑldiz smɔlɝ fɔɹs.

We have to stay, Ituralde thought, watching his men work, digging in, erecting a palisade. He hated the thought of cutting down trees in a stedding. He'd known a few Ogier in his time, and respected them. These massive oaks probably held some lingering strength from the days when the Ogier had lived here. Cutting them down was a crime. But you did what you had to. Running might gain him more time, but it might just as easily lose him time. He had a few days here before the Seanchan hit him. If he could dig in well, he might force them into a siege. The stedding would make them hesitant, and the forests would work to the advantage of Ituralde's smaller force.

hi heɪɾəd lɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɡɛt pɪn ɪn. ðət wɑz pɹɑbli waɪ hid kənsɪɾɝd fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ, ivən ðoʊ, dip daʊn, hiɾ ɔlɹɛɾi noʊn ðəɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm tə stɑp ɹʌnɪŋ. ðə sintʃæn hæd faɪnəli kɑt hɪm.

He hated letting himself get pinned in. That was probably why he'd considered for so long, even though, deep down, he'd already known that it was time to stop running. The Seanchan had finally caught him.

hi kəntɪnjuɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹæŋks, nɑɾɪŋ tə wɝkɪŋ mɛn, lɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bi sin. hi hæd fɔɹɾi θaʊzən tʃɹups lɛft, wɪtʃ wɑz ə mɑɹvəl, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ði ɑdz ðeɪ hæd feɪst. ðiz mɛn ʃəɾ əv dɪzɝɾɪd. bʌt ðeɪd sin ɪm wɪn ɪmpɑsəbəl bæɾəl æftɝ ɪmpɑsəbəl bæɾəl, tɔsɪŋ bɔl æftɝ bɔl ɪndə ði ɛɹ tə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ən ɡɹeɪɾɝ əplɔz. ðeɪ θɔɾ i wɑz ənstɑpəbəl. ðeɪ dɪdn ʌndɝstæn ðət wən wʌn tɔs mɔɹ bɔlz ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ɪt wɑzn dʒʌs ðə ʃoʊ ðət bɪkeɪm mɔɹ spɛktækjəlɝ.

He continued along the ranks, nodding to working men, letting himself be seen. He had forty thousand troops left, which was a marvel, considering the odds they had faced. These men should have deserted. But they'd seen him win impossible battle after impossible battle, tossing ball after ball into the air to greater and greater applause. They thought he was unstoppable. They didn't understand that when one tossed more balls into the air, it wasn't just the show that became more spectacular.

ðə fɔl ət ði ɛnd ɡɹu mɔɹ spɛktækjəlɝ əz wɛl.

The fall at the end grew more spectacular as well.

hi kɛpt ɪz dɑɹk θɔts tə hɪmsɛlf əz i ən ɹədʒɑbi kəntɪnjud θɹu ðə fɔɹəstəd kæmp, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə pælɪsɑd. ɪt wɑz pɹəɡɹɛsɪŋ naɪsli, ðə mɛn sɛɾɪŋ θɪk tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋks ɪndə fɹɛʃli dʌɡ tʃɹɔfs. æftɝ ɪz ɪnspɛkʃən, ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd tə hɪmsɛlf. "wi steɪ, ɹədʒɑbi. pæs ðə wɝd."

He kept his dark thoughts to himself as he and Rajabi continued through the forested camp, inspecting the palisade. It was progressing nicely, the men setting thick tree trunks into freshly dug troughs. After his inspection, Ituralde nodded to himself. "We stay, Rajabi. Pass the word."

"sʌm ə ði ʌðɝz seɪ ðət steɪɪŋ hɪɹ minz daɪɪŋ fəɹ ʃʊɹ," ɹədʒɑbi ɹɪspɑndɪd.

"Some of the others say that staying here means dying for sure," Rajabi responded.

"ðeɪɹ ɹɔŋ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd.

"They're wrong," Ituralde said.

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"nʌθɪŋ ɪz ʃʊɹ, ɹədʒɑbi," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "fɪl ðiz tʃɹiz ɪnsaɪd ðə pælɪsɑd wɪð ɑɹtʃɝz; ðəl bi ɔlmoʊst əz ɪfɛktɪv əz taʊɝz. wɪl nid tə sɛɾ ʌp ə kɪlɪŋ fild aʊtsaɪd. kʌt daʊn əz mɛni tʃɹiz ɝaʊn ðə pælɪsɑd hɪɹ əz pɑsəbəl, ðən sɛt ðə lɔɡz ɪnsaɪɾ əz bæɹiɝz, ə sɛkən laɪn ə ɹitʃɹit.

"Nothing is sure, Rajabi," Ituralde said. "Fill these trees inside the palisade with archers; they'll be almost as effective as towers. We'll need to set up a killing field outside. Cut down as many trees around the palisade here as possible, then set the logs inside as barriers, a second line of retreat.

wɪl hoʊl stʃɹɔŋ. pɝhæps aɪm ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ðoʊz tæɹɑbənɝz, ən ðəl ɹaɪd tə eɪɾ ʌs. əɹ meɪbi ðə kɪŋ əz ə hɪɾən ɑɹmi stæʃt əweɪ tə dɪfɛn ʌs. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, meɪbi wɪl faɪɾ əm ɔf hɪɹ ɑn əɹ oʊn. wɪl si haʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ laɪk faɪɾɪŋ wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn. wɪl sɝvaɪv."

We'll hold strong. Perhaps I'm wrong about those Taraboners, and they'll ride to aid us. Or maybe the king has a hidden army stashed away to defend us. Blood and ashes, maybe we'll fight them off here on our own. We'll see how much they like fighting without their damane. We'll survive."

ɹədʒɑbi stʃɹeɪɾənd vɪzəbli, ɡɹoʊɪŋ kɑnfəɾənt. ðət wɑz ðə kaɪndə tɔk ɪɾɝɑldi nu hi ɪkspɛktəd. laɪk ði ʌðɝz, ɹədʒɑbi tʃɹʌstɪd ðə lɪɾəl wʊlf. ðeɪ dɪdn bɪliv i kəd feɪl.

Rajabi straightened visibly, growing confident. That was the kind of talk Ituralde knew he expected. Like the others, Rajabi trusted the Little Wolf. They didn't believe he could fail.

ɪɾɝɑldi nu bɛɾɝ. bʌɾ ɪf jə wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, jə dɪɾ ɪt wɪð dɪɡnəɾi. ðə jʌŋ ɪɾɝɑldi hæɾ ɔfən dʒɹimd ʌv wɔɹz, ʌv ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv bæɾəl. ði oʊld ɪɾɝɑldi nu ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sətʃ θɪŋ əz ɡlɔɹi tə bi hæɾ ɪn bæɾəl. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɑnɝ.

Ituralde knew better. But if you were going to die, you did it with dignity. The young Ituralde had often dreamed of wars, of the glory of battle. The old Ituralde knew there was no such thing as glory to be had in battle. But there was honor.

"maɪ lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi!" ə ɹʌnɝ kɔld, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ði ənfɪnɪʃt pælɪsɑd wɔl. hi wɑz ə bɔɪ, jʌŋ ɪnʌf ðət ðə sintʃæn wəd pɹɑbli lɛɾ ɪm laɪv. ʌðɝwaɪz ɪɾɝɑldi wʊɾə sɛn ðə læd, ən ðoʊz laɪk hɪm, əweɪ.

"My Lord Ituralde!" a runner called, trotting along the inside of the unfinished palisade wall. He was a boy, young enough that the Seanchan would probably let him live. Otherwise Ituralde would have sent the lad, and those like him, away.

"jɛs?" ɪɾɝɑldi æskt, tɝnɪŋ. ɹədʒɑbi stʊd laɪk ə smɔl maʊntən əɾ ɪz saɪd.

"Yes?" Ituralde asked, turning. Rajabi stood like a small mountain at his side.

"ə mæn," ðə bɔɪ sɛd, pʌfɪŋ. "ðə skaʊts kɑɾ ɪm wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ðə stɛɾɪŋ."

"A man," the boy said, puffing. "The scouts caught him walking into the stedding."

"kʌm tə faɪt fəɹ ʌs?" ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ənkɑmən fəɹ ən ɑɹmi tə dʒɹɔ ɹəkɹuts. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz ðoʊz tɛmptəd baɪ ðə lʊɹ ʌv ɡlɔɹi, əɹ ət lis baɪ ðə lʊɹ ə stɛɾi milz.

"Come to fight for us?" Ituralde said. It was not uncommon for an army to draw recruits. There were always those tempted by the lure of glory, or at least by the lure of steady meals.

"noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd," ðə bɔɪ sɛd, pʌfɪŋ. "hi sɛz hiz kʌm tə si ju."

"No, my Lord," the boy said, puffing. "He says he's come to see you."

"sintʃæn?" ɹədʒɑbi bɑɹkt.

"Seanchan?" Rajabi barked.

ðə bɔɪ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ. bʌt hiz ɡɑt naɪs kloʊðz."

The boy shook his head. "No. But he's got nice clothes."

səm lɔɹdz mɛsənʒɝ, ðɛn. dəmɑni, əɹ pɝhæps ə tæɹɑbənɝ ɹɛnəɡeɪd. huɛvɝ i wɑz, hi kəd hɑɹdli meɪk ðɛɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən wɝs. "æn i keɪm əloʊn?"

Some lord's messenger, then. Domani, or perhaps a Taraboner renegade. Whoever he was, he could hardly make their situation worse. "And he came alone?"

"jɛs, sɝ."

"Yes, sir."

bɹeɪv mæn. "bɹɪŋ hɪm, ðɛn," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd.

Brave man. "Bring him, then," Ituralde said.

"wɛɹ wɪl jə ɹəsiv hɪm, maɪ lɔɹd?"

"Where will you receive him, my Lord?"

"wʌt?" ɪɾɝɑldi snæpt. "ju θɪŋk ɪm səm fænsi mɝtʃənt wɪð ə pæləs? ðə fil hɪɹ wɪl du. ɡoʊ ɡɛt hɪm, bʌt teɪk jəɹ taɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk. ən meɪk ʃʊɹ hiz pɹɑpɝli ɡɑɹɾəd."

"What?" Ituralde snapped. "You think I'm some fancy merchant with a palace? The field here will do. Go get him, but take your time getting back. And make sure he's properly guarded."

ðə bɔɪ nɑɾəd ən ɹæn ɔf. ɪɾɝɑldi weɪvd oʊvɝ səm soʊlʒɝz ən sɛn əm ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ weɪkeɪɾə ən ði ʌðɝ ɔfəsɝz. ʃɪmɹɑn wɑz dɛd, bɝn tə tʃɑɹ baɪ ə deɪmeɪnz faɪɝbɔl. tu bæd, ðæt.

The boy nodded and ran off. Ituralde waved over some soldiers and sent them running for Wakeda and the other officers. Shimron was dead, burned to char by a damane's fireball. Too bad, that.

ɪɾɝɑldi wəd ɹæðɝ əv kɛpt ɪm ðən mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz.

Ituralde would rather have kept him than many of the others.

moʊst ə ði ɔfəsɝz ɝaɪv bɪfɔɹ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ. læŋki æŋkɑɹ. wʌn-aɪd weɪkeɪɾə, hu maɪɾ ʌðɝwaɪz əv bɪn ə hænsəm mæn. skwɑt mɛlɑɹnd. juθfəl lɪdʒɹɪn, hu kəntɪnjud tə fɑloʊ ɪɾɝɑldi æftɝ ɪz fɑðɝz dɛθ.

Most of the officers arrived before the stranger. Lanky Ankaer. One-eyed Wakeda, who might otherwise have been a handsome man. Squat Melarned. Youthful Lidrin, who continued to follow Ituralde after his father's death.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs aɪ hɪɹ?" weɪkeɪɾə æskt, foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz əz i stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp. "wɝ steɪɪŋ ɪn ðɪs dɛθ tʃɹæp? ɹoʊɾəl, wi doʊn əv ðə tʃɹups tə ɹɪzɪst. ɪf ðeɪ kʌm, wɪl bi tʃɹæp hɪɹ."

"What is this I hear?" Wakeda asked, folding his arms as he strode up. "We're staying in this death trap? Rodel, we don't have the troops to resist. If they come, we'll be trapped here."

"jɔɹ ɹaɪt," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd sɪmpli.

"You're right," Ituralde said simply.

weɪkeɪɾə tɝn tə ði ʌðɝz, ðən bæk tə ɪɾɝɑldi, ə lɪɾəl ə hɪz ɪɹɪteɪʃən dɪfleɪɾɪd ɪn ðə feɪs ʌv ɪɾɝɑldiz fɹæŋk ænsɝ. "wɛl . . . waɪ doʊnt wi ɹʌn, ðɛn?" hi blʌstɝɾ ə lɑt lɛs naʊ ðən i hæd dʒʌs mʌnθs əɡoʊ, wən ɪɾɝɑldi hæd fɝs bɪɡʌn ðɪs kæmpeɪn.

Wakeda turned to the others, then back to Ituralde, a little of his irritation deflated in the face of Ituralde's frank answer. "Well . . . why don't we run, then?" He blustered a lot less now than he had just months ago, when Ituralde had first begun this campaign.

"aɪ woʊnt ɡɪv jə ʃʊɡɝ ən laɪz," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ əɾ əm itʃ ɪn tɝn. "wɝ ɪn ə bæd ʃeɪp. bʌt wɪl bi ɪn ə wɝs ʃeɪp ɪf wi ɹʌn. wiv ɡɑt noʊ mɔɹ hoʊlz tə haɪɾ ɪn. ðiz tʃɹiz wɪl wɝk tə əɹ ædvæntɪdʒ, ən wi kən fɔɹɾɪfaɪ. ðə stɛɾɪŋ wɪl nɪɡeɪt ðə deɪmeɪn, ən ðəɾ əloʊn ɪz wɝθ ðə pɹaɪs ə steɪɪŋ. wi faɪt hɪɹ."

"I won't give you sugar and lies," Ituralde said, looking at them each in turn. "We're in a bad shape. But we'll be in a worse shape if we run. We've got no more holes to hide in. These trees will work to our advantage, and we can fortify. The stedding will negate the damane, and that alone is worth the price of staying. We fight here."

æŋkɑɹ nɑɾəd, simɪŋ tə ʌndɝstæn ðə ɡɹævəɾi ʌv ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən. "wi hæv tə tʃɹʌs hɪm, weɪkeɪɾə.

Ankaer nodded, seeming to understand the gravity of the situation. "We have to trust him, Wakeda.

hiz lɛɾ əs ɹaɪt soʊ fɑɹ."

He's led us right so far."

weɪkeɪɾə nɑɾəd. "aɪ səpoʊz."

Wakeda nodded. "I suppose."

blʌɾi fulz. fɔɹ mʌnθs əɡoʊ, hæf ə ðɛm wʊɾə kɪld ɪm ɑn saɪt fəɹ steɪɪŋ lɔɪəl tə ðə kɪŋ. naʊ ðeɪ θɔɾ i kəd də ði ɪmpɑsəbəl. ɪt wɑz ə pɪɾi; hi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk i cʊɾə bɹɔɾ əm bæk tə ælsələm əz lɔɪəlɪsts. "ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ ət vɛɹiəs spɑts əlɔŋ ðɛɹ fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən. "hɪɹz wʌt wɝ gɑnə də tə ʃɔɹ ʌp ðə wik pɔɪns. aɪ wɑnt . . ."

Bloody fools. Four months ago, half of them would have killed him on sight for staying loyal to the king. Now they thought he could do the impossible. It was a pity; he was beginning to think he could have brought them back to Alsalam as loyalists. "All right," he said, pointing at various spots along their fortification. "Here's what we're going to do to shore up the weak points. I want . . ."

hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf əz i sɔ ə ɡɹup əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə klɪɹɪŋ. ðə mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪ, əkʌmpənid baɪ ə skwɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝz, ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ ə mæn ɪn ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld.

He trailed off as he saw a group approaching through the clearing. The messenger boy, accompanied by a squad of soldiers, escorting a man in red and gold.

sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə nukʌmɝ dʒɹu ɪɾɝɑldiz aɪz. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ðə haɪt; ðə jʌŋ mæn wɑz əz tɔl əz ən il, ən fɛɹ ə hɛɹ laɪk əm əz wɛl. bʌt noʊ il dʒɹɛst ɪn ə faɪn ɹɛd koʊt wɪð ʃɑɹp ɡoʊldən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. ðəɹ wɑz ə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd, ən ðə weɪ ðə nukʌmɝ wɔk meɪɾ ɪɾɝɑldi θɪŋk i nu haʊ tə juz ɪt. hi stʃɹoʊd wɪð fɝm, dɪtɝmən stɛps, əz ɪf i θɔt ðə soʊlʒɝz ɝaʊn ɪm ən ɑnɝ ɡɑɹd. ə lɔɹd, ðɛn, ən wʌn əkʌstəm tə kəmænd. waɪ hæɾ i kʌm ɪn pɝsən, ɹæðɝ ðən sɛndɪŋ ə mɛsənʒɝ?

Something about the newcomer drew Ituralde's eyes. Perhaps it was the height; the young man was as tall as an Aiel, and fair of hair like them as well. But no Aiel dressed in a fine red coat with sharp golden embroidery. There was a sword at his side, and the way the newcomer walked made Ituralde think he knew how to use it. He strode with firm, determined steps, as if he thought the soldiers around him an honor guard. A lord, then, and one accustomed to command. Why had he come in person, rather than sending a messenger?

ðə jʌŋ lɔɹd stɑpt ə ʃɔɹt lɛŋθ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪɾɝɑldi ən ɪz dʒɛnɝəlz, lʊkɪŋ əɾ itʃ ə ðɛm ɪn tɝn, ðən foʊkəst ɑn ɪɾɝɑldi. "ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi?" hi æskt. wʌɾ æksɛnt wɑz ðæt? ændɔɝən?

The young lord stopped a short length in front of Ituralde and his generals, looking at each of them in turn, then focused on Ituralde. "Rodel Ituralde?" he asked. What accent was that? Andoran?

"jɛs," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd kɔʃəsli.

"Yes," Ituralde said cautiously.

ðə jʌŋ mæn nɑɾəd. "bæʃɪɹz dɪskɹɪpʃən wɑz ækjɝət. jə əpɪɹ tə bi bɑksɪŋ jɝsɛlf ɪn, hɪɹ. dʒju ɑnəsli ɪkspɛk tə hoʊld əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn ɑɹmi? ðeɪ ɑɹ mɛni taɪmz jəɹ saɪz, ən jəɹ tæɹɑbən ælaɪz də nɑɾ əpɪɹ . . . iɡɝ tə dʒɔɪn jə ɪn jəɹ dɪfɛns."

The young man nodded. "Bashere's description was accurate. You appear to be boxing yourself in, here. Do you honestly expect to hold against the Seanchan army? They are many times your size, and your Tarabon allies do not appear . . . eager to join you in your defense."

hi hæd ɡʊɾ ɪntɛlədʒəns, huɛvɝ i wɑz. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ɪn ðə hæbəɾ ə dɪskʌsɪŋ maɪ dɪfɛnsəz wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒɝz." ɪɾɝɑldi stʌɾid ðə jʌŋ lɔɹd. hi wɑz fɪt - lin ən hɑɹd, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl wɪð ðə koʊɾ ɑn. hi feɪvɝɾ ɪz ɹaɪt hænd, ən ɑn kloʊsɝ ɪnspɛkʃən, ɪɾɝɑldi noʊɾəst ðət ðə lɛf hænd wɑz mɪsɪŋ. boʊθ ə hɪz fɹɑɹmz hæd səm kaɪndə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊl tætu ɑn ðɛm.

He had good intelligence, whoever he was. "I am not in the habit of discussing my defenses with strangers." Ituralde studied the young lord. He was fit - lean and hard, though it was difficult to tell with the coat on. He favored his right hand, and on closer inspection, Ituralde noticed that the left hand was missing. Both of his forearms had some kind of strange red and gold tattoo on them.

ðoʊz aɪz. ðoʊz wɝ aɪz wɪtʃ hæd sin dɛθ ə nʌmbɝ ə taɪmz. nɑt dʒʌst ə jʌŋ lɔɹd. ə jʌŋ dʒɛnɝəl. ɪɾɝɑldi nɛɹoʊɾ ɪz aɪz. "hu ɑɹ ju?"

Those eyes. Those were eyes which had seen death a number of times. Not just a young lord. A young general. Ituralde narrowed his eyes. "Who are you?"

ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. "aɪ æm ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ən aɪ nid ju. jə ən jəɹ ɑɹmi."

The stranger met his eyes. "I am Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn. And I need you. You and your army."

sɛvɹəl ə ðoʊz wɪð ɪɾɝɑldi kɝst, ən ɪɾɝɑldi ɡlænst ət ðɛm. weɪkeɪɾə wɑz ɪnkɹɛdʒələs, ɹədʒɑbi sɝpɹaɪzd, jʌŋ lɪdʒɹɪn oʊpənli dɪsmɪsɪv.

Several of those with Ituralde cursed, and Ituralde glanced at them. Wakeda was incredulous, Rajabi surprised, young Lidrin openly dismissive.

ɪɾɝɑldi lʊk bæk ət ðə nukʌmɝ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ðɪs juθ? hi səpoʊzd ɪt kəd bi pɑsəbəl. moʊst ɹumɝz əɡɹid ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ə jʌŋ mæn wɪð ɹɛd hɛɹ. bʌt, ðɛn, ɹumɝz ɔlsoʊ kleɪmd i wɑz tɛn fit tɔl, ən stɪl ʌðɝz sɛɾ ɪz aɪz ɡloʊɾ ɪn dɪm laɪt. ən ðən ðəɹ wɝ ðə stɔɹiz ə hɪm əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə skaɪ ət fɑlm. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdnt noʊ ɪf i bɪliv ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən hæd bɪn ɹibɔɹn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs!

Ituralde looked back at the newcomer. The Dragon Reborn? This youth? He supposed it could be possible. Most rumors agreed that the Dragon Reborn was a young man with red hair. But, then, rumors also claimed he was ten feet tall, and still others said his eyes glowed in dim light. And then there were the stories of him appearing in the sky at Falme. Blood and ashes, Ituralde didn't know if he believed that the Dragon had been reborn in the first place!

"aɪ hævən taɪm tə ɑɹɡju," ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ sɛd, feɪs ɪmpæsɪv. hi simd . . . oʊldɝ ðən i lʊkt.

"I haven't time to argue," the stranger said, face impassive. He seemed . . . older than he looked.

hi dɪdn əpɪɹ tə kɛɹ ðəɾ i wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɑɹm soʊlʒɝz. ɪn fækt, hɪz kʌmɪŋ əloʊn . . . ɪt ʃʊɾə sim laɪk sətʃ ə fulɪʃ ækt. ɪnstɛɾ ɪt meɪɾ ɪɾɝɑldi θɔtfəl. oʊnli wʌn sətʃ əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf kəd stʃɹaɪɾ ɪndə ə wɔɹ kæmp laɪk ðɪs, kəmplitli əloʊn, ən ɪkspɛk tə bi oʊbeɪd.

He didn't appear to care that he was surrounded by armed soldiers. In fact, his coming alone . . . it should have seemed like such a foolish act. Instead it made Ituralde thoughtful. Only one such as the Dragon Reborn himself could stride into a war camp like this, completely alone, and expect to be obeyed.

bɝn hɪm, ɪf ðət fæk baɪ ɪtsɛlf dɪdn meɪk ɪɾɝɑldi wɑnə bɪliv hɪm. iðɝ ðɪs mæn wɑz u hi kleɪm tə bi əɹ i wɑz ən ʌɾɝ lunətɪk.

Burn him, if that fact by itself didn't make Ituralde want to believe him. Either this man was who he claimed to be or he was an utter lunatic.

"ɪf wi ɡoʊ aʊtsaɪd ðə stɛɾɪŋ, əl pɹuv aɪ kən tʃænəl," ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ sɛd. "ðæt ʃəd kaʊn fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ. ɡɪmi liv, ən əl əv tɛn θaʊzən il hɪɹ ən sɛvɹəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔl ə hum wɪl swɛɹ tə jə ðəɾ aɪm u aɪ seɪ."

"If we go outside the stedding, I will prove I can channel," the stranger said. "That should count for something. Give me leave, and I'll have ten thousand Aiel here and several Aes Sedai, all of whom will swear to you that I am who I say."

ðə ɹumɝz ɔlsoʊ sɛɾ il fɑloʊd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ɪɾɝɑldi kɔft ən ɡlænst əbaʊɾ ənkʌmftəbli. mɛni hæd bɪn dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ tə ɪɾɝɑldi. wɪð ðə ɹaɪt wɝdz, ðɪs ɹænd ælθɹ - əɹ huɛvɝ i wɑz - maɪt bi eɪbəl tɝn ɪɾɝɑldiz kæmp əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf.

The rumors also said Aiel followed the Dragon Reborn. The men around Ituralde coughed and glanced about uncomfortably. Many had been Dragonsworn before coming to Ituralde. With the right words, this Rand al'Thor - or whoever he was - might be able turn Ituralde's camp against itself.

"ivən ɪf wi əsum ðəɾ aɪ bɪliv ju," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd kɛɹfəli, "aɪ doʊn si ðəɾ ɪt mæɾɝz. aɪ hæv ə wɔɹ tə faɪt. juv ʌðɝ bɪznəs tə kənsɝn ju, aɪ əsum."

"Even if we assume that I believe you," Ituralde said carefully, "I don't see that it matters. I have a war to fight. You have other business to concern you, I assume."

"ju ɑɹ maɪ kənsɝn," ælθɹ sɛd, aɪz soʊ hɑɹd ðət ðeɪ simd ɹɛɾi tə bɝoʊ ɪndə ɪɾɝɑldiz skʌl ən sɝtʃ əbaʊɾ ɪnsaɪd fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ə jus. "ju mʌs meɪk pis wɪð ðə sintʃæn. ðɪs wɔɹ ɡeɪnz əs nʌθɪŋ. aɪ wɑn jə ʌp ɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz; aɪ kæn spɛɹ mɛn tə ɡɑɹd ðə blaɪt, ən ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz ðɛmsɛlvz əv əbændən ðɛɹ duɾiz."

"You are my concern," al'Thor said, eyes so hard that they seemed ready to burrow into Ituralde's skull and search about inside for anything of use. "You must make peace with the Seanchan. This war gains us nothing. I want you up on the Borderlands; I can't spare men to guard the Blight, and the Borderlanders themselves have abandoned their duties."

"aɪ hæv ɔɹɾɝz," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. weɪt. hi wʊdn də əz ðɪs juθ æskt ɪf i dɪdn əv ɔɹɾɝz. ɪksɛpt . . . ðoʊz aɪz. ælsələm hæd hæɾ aɪz laɪk ðæt, wən ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ jʌŋɡɝ. aɪz ðət dɪmændəɾ oʊbiɾiəns.

"I have orders," Ituralde said, shaking his head. Wait. He wouldn't do as this youth asked if he didn't have orders. Except . . . those eyes. Alsalam had had eyes like that, when they were both younger. Eyes that demanded obedience.

"jɔɹ ɔɹɾɝz," ælθɹ sɛd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ fɹəm ðə kɪŋ? ðəɾ ɪz waɪ jə θɹoʊ jʊɹsɛlvz əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn əz jə du?"

"Your orders," al'Thor said. "They are from the king? That is why you throw yourselves against the Seanchan as you do?"

ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd.

Ituralde nodded.

"aɪv hɝɾ ə ju, ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi," ælθɹ sɛd. "mɛn aɪ tʃɹʌst, mɛn aɪ ɹɪspɛkt, tʃɹʌst ən ɹɪspɛk ju. ɹæðɝ ðən fliɪŋ ən haɪɾɪŋ, jə hʌŋkɝ daʊn hɪɹ tə faɪɾ ə bæɾəl jə noʊ wɪl kɪl ju. ɔl kəz ə jəɹ lɔɪəlti tə jəɹ kɪŋ. aɪ kəmɛn ðæt. bʌɾ ɪts taɪm tə tɝn əweɪ ən faɪɾ ə bæɾəl ðət minz sʌmθɪŋ. wʌn ðət minz ɛvɹiθɪŋ. kʌm wɪð mi, ən əl ɡɪv jə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ɑɹæd dumən."

"I've heard of you, Rodel Ituralde," al'Thor said. "Men I trust, men I respect, trust and respect you. Rather than fleeing and hiding, you hunker down here to fight a battle you know will kill you. All because of your loyalty to your king. I commend that. But it is time to turn away and fight a battle that means something. One that means everything. Come with me, and I'll give you the throne of Arad Doman."

ɪɾɝɑldi stʊɾ ʌp ʃɑɹpli, əlɝt. "æftɝ kəmɛndɪŋ maɪ lɔɪəlti, jə ɪkspɛk mi tə ənsit maɪ oʊn kɪŋ!"

Ituralde stood up sharply, alert. "After commending my loyalty, you expect me to unseat my own king!"

"jɔɹ kɪŋ ɪz dɛd," ælθɹ sɛd. "iðɝ ðæt, əɹ ɪz maɪn əz bɪn mɛltəd laɪk wæks. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ, aɪ θɪŋk ɡɹeɪndəl əz hɪm. aɪ si hɝ tʌtʃ ɑn ðə keɪɑs ɪn ðɪs lænd. wʌtɛvɝ ɔɹɾɝz juv laɪkli keɪm fɹəm hɝ. waɪ ʃi wɑns jə faɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn, aɪ hævən jɛt bɪn eɪbəl tə dətɝmən."

"Your king is dead," al'Thor said. "Either that, or his mind has been melted like wax. More and more, I think Graendal has him. I see her touch on the chaos in this land. Whatever orders you have likely came from her. Why she wants you fighting the Seanchan, I haven't yet been able to determine."

ɪɾɝɑldi snɔɹɾɪd. "ju spik ʌv wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən əz ɪf juv hæɾ əɹ əz ə dɪnɝ ɡɛst."

Ituralde snorted. "You speak of one of the Forsaken as if you've had her as a dinner guest."

ælθɹ mɛɾ ɪz aɪz əɡɛn. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ itʃ ə ðɛm - ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ðɛɹ mænɝɪzəmz, ðə weɪ ðeɪ spik ən ækt - əz ɪf aɪv noʊn əm fəɹ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ əm bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ maɪ oʊn tʃaɪldhʊd, səmtaɪmz. aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

Al'Thor met his eyes again. "I remember each of them - their faces, their mannerisms, the way they speak and act - as if I've known them for a thousand years. I remember them better than I remember my own childhood, sometimes. I am the Dragon Reborn."

ɪɾɝɑldi blɪŋkt. bɝn mi, hi θɔt. aɪ bɪliv hɪm. blʌɾi æʃəz! "lɛts . . . lɛts si ðɪs pɹuf ə jʊɹz."

Ituralde blinked. Burn me, he thought. I believe him. Bloody ashes! "Let's . . . let's see this proof of yours."

ðəɹ wɝ əbdʒɛkʃənz, ʌv kɔɹs, moʊsli fɹəm lɪdʒɹɪn, hu θɔɾ ɪt tu deɪnʒɝəs. ði ʌðɝz wɝ ʃeɪkən. hɪɹ wɑz ðə mæn ðeɪd swɔɹn ðɛmsɛlvz tə wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ miɾɪŋ hɪm. ðəɹ sim tə bi ə . . . ə fɔɹs əbaʊɾ ælθɹ, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪɾɝɑldi ɪn, dɪmændɪŋ ðəɾ i də əz æskt. wɛl, hid si ðə pɹuf, fɝst.

There were objections, of course, mostly from Lidrin, who thought it too dangerous. The others were shaken. Here was the man they'd sworn themselves to without ever meeting him. There seemed to be a . . . a force about al'Thor, drawing Ituralde in, demanding that he do as asked. Well, he'd see the proof, first.

ðeɪ sɛn ɹʌnɝz fəɹ hɔɹsəz tə ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ, bʌɾ ælθɹ spoʊk əz ɪf ɪɾɝɑldi wɑz ɪz mæn ɔlɹɛɾi. "pɝhæps ælsələm laɪvz," ælθɹ sɛɾ əz ðeɪ weɪɾəd. "ɪf soʊ, aɪ kən si ðət jə wəd nɑt wɑn ɪz θɹoʊn. wəd jə laɪk ɑmɑdɪʃiə? əl nid sʌmwʌn tə ɹul ðəɹ ən kip ən aɪ ɑn ðə sintʃæn. ðə waɪtkloʊks faɪt ðəɹ naʊ; aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf əl bi eɪbəl tə stɑp ðət kɑnflɪk bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl."

They sent runners for horses to ride out of the stedding, but al'Thor spoke as if Ituralde was his man already. "Perhaps Alsalam lives," al'Thor said as they waited. "If so, I can see that you would not want his throne. Would you like Amadicia? I will need someone to rule there and keep an eye on the Seanchan. The Whitecloaks fight there now; I'm not sure if I'll be able to stop that conflict before the Last Battle."

ðə læs bæɾəl. laɪt! "aɪ woʊn teɪk ɪɾ ɪf jə kɪl ðə kɪŋ ðɛɹ," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "ɪf ðə waɪtkloʊks əv ɔlɹɛɾi kɪl hɪm, əɹ ɪf ðə sintʃæn hæv, ðən pɝhæps."

The Last Battle. Light! "I won't take it if you kill the king there," Ituralde said. "If the Whitecloaks have already killed him, or if the Seanchan have, then perhaps."

kɪŋ! wʌt wɑz i seɪɪŋ? bɝn ju! hi θɔt tə hɪmsɛlf. ət list weɪɾ əntɪl ðə pɹuf ɪz ɡɪvən bɪfɔɹ əɡɹiɪŋ tə æksɛp θɹoʊnz! ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ əbaʊt ðɪs mæn, ðə weɪ hi dɪskʌst ɪvɛns laɪk ðə læs bæɾəl - ɪvɛns ðət mænkaɪn hæd bɪn fɪɹɪŋ fəɹ θaʊzənz ə jɪɹz - əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ aɪɾəmz ɑn ðə deɪli kæmp ɹipɔɹt.

King! What was he saying? Burn you! he thought to himself. At least wait until the proof is given before agreeing to accept thrones! There was a way about this man, the way he discussed events like the Last Battle - events that mankind had been fearing for thousands of years - as if they were items on the daily camp report.

soʊlʒɝz ɝaɪvd wɪð ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ən ɪɾɝɑldi maʊntəd, əz dɪɾ ælθɹ, weɪkeɪɾə, ɹədʒɑbi, æŋkɑɹ, mɛlɑɹnd, lɪdʒɹɪn ən ə hæf-dʌzən lɛsɝ ɔfəsɝz.

Soldiers arrived with their horses, and Ituralde mounted, as did al'Thor, Wakeda, Rajabi, Ankaer, Melarned, Lidrin and a half-dozen lesser officers.

"aɪv bɹɔɾ ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ʌv il ɪndə jəɹ lænz," ɹænd ælθɹ sɛɾ əz ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪd. "aɪ hæd hoʊp tə juz əm tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ lɔŋɡɝ ðən aɪd wɪʃt. aɪm plænɪŋ tə sɪkjʊɹ ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl; pɝhæps wʌns aɪ hæv əm ɪn hænd, əl bi eɪbəl tə ɪmpɹuv ðə stəbɪlɪɾi ʌv ði ɛɹiə. wʌt dʒju θɪŋk?"

"I've brought a large number of Aiel into your lands," Rand al'Thor said as they began to ride. "I had hoped to use them to restore order, but they are taking longer than I'd wished. I'm planning to secure the members of the merchant council; perhaps once I have them in hand, I'll be able to improve the stability of the area. What do you think?"

ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdnt noʊ wʌt tə θɪŋk. sɪkjʊɹɪŋ ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl? ðət saʊndəd laɪk kɪdnæpɪŋ ðɛm. wʌt hæɾ ɪɾɝɑldi ɡɑɾən hɪmsɛlf ɪntu? "ɪt kəd wɝk," hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf seɪɪŋ. "laɪt, ɪts pɹɑbli ðə bɛs plæn, ɔl θɪŋz kənsɪɾɝd."

Ituralde didn't know what to think. Securing the merchant council? That sounded like kidnapping them. What had Ituralde gotten himself into? "It could work," he found himself saying. "Light, it's probably the best plan, all things considered."

ælθɹ nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ əz ðeɪ pæst aʊɾ ə ðə pælɪsɑɾ ən muvd aʊɾ əlɔŋ ə tʃɹeɪl təwɔɹd ði ɛdʒ ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ. "aɪl əv tə sɪkjʊɹ ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, ɛniweɪ. əl kɛɹ fəɹ jəɹ hoʊmlænd. bɝn ðoʊz bɔɹɾɝləndɝz! wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ ʌp tə? noʊ. noʊ, nɑt jɛt. ðeɪ kən weɪt. noʊ, hɪl du. hi kən hoʊld ɪt. əl sɛn ɪm wɪð æʃəmən." sʌɾənli, ælθɹ tɝn tə ɪɾɝɑldi. "wʌt kəd jə də ɪf aɪ ɡeɪv jə ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn u kəd tʃænəl?"

Al'Thor nodded, looking forward as they passed out of the palisade and moved out along a trail toward the edge of the stedding. "I'll have to secure the Borderlands, anyway. I will care for your homeland. Burn those Borderlanders! What are they up to? No. No, not yet. They can wait. No, he'll do. He can hold it. I'll send him with Asha'man." Suddenly, al'Thor turned to Ituralde. "What could you do if I gave you a hundred men who could channel?"

"mædmən?"

"Madmen?"

"noʊ, moʊst ə ðɛm ɑɹ steɪbəl," ælθɹ sɛd, teɪkɪŋ noʊ əpɛɹən əfɛns. "wʌtɛvɝ mædnəs ðeɪ ɪnkɝd bɪfɔɹ aɪ klɛnz ðə teɪn ɪz stɪl ðəɹ - ɹimuvɪŋ ðə teɪn dɪdn hil əm - bʌt fju ʌv əm wɝ fɑɹ ɡɔn. ən ðeɪ woʊnt ɡɛt wɝs, naʊ ðət seɪɾɪn ɪz klin."

"No, most of them are stable," al'Thor said, taking no apparent offense. "Whatever madness they incurred before I cleansed the taint is still there - removing the taint didn't heal them - but few of them were far gone. And they won't get worse, now that saidin is clean."

seɪɾɪn? klin? ɪf ɪɾɝɑldi hæɾ ɪz oʊn mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. . . . hɪz oʊn deɪmeɪn, ɪn ə weɪ.

Saidin? Clean? If Ituralde had his own men who could channel. . . . His own damane, in a way.

ɪɾɝɑldi skɹætʃt ɪz tʃɪn. ɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ əɾ ɪm kwɪkli - bʌt, ðɛn, ə dʒɛnɝəl hæd tə bi eɪbəl tə ɹiækt kwɪkli. "aɪ kəd juz əm wɛl," hi sɛd. "vɛɹi wɛl."

Ituralde scratched his chin. It was coming at him quickly - but, then, a general had to be able to react quickly. "I could use them well," he said. "Very well."

"ɡʊd," ælθɹ sɛd. ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðə stɛɾɪŋ; ði ɛɹ fɛl dɪfɹənt. "juv ɡɑɾ ə lɑɾ ə læn tə wɑtʃ, bʌt mɛni ʌv ðə tʃænlɝz əl ɡɪv jə kən spɪn ɡeɪtweɪz."

"Good," al'Thor said. They had left the stedding; the air felt different. "You've got a lot of land to watch, but many of the channelers I'll give you can spin gateways."

"ɡeɪtweɪz?" ɪɾɝɑldi æskt.

"Gateways?" Ituralde asked.

ælθɹ ɡlænst ət hɪm, ðən sim tə ɡɹɪɾ ɪz tiθ, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz, ʃeɪkɪŋ əz ɪf nɔzieɪɾəd.

Al'Thor glanced at him, then seemed to grit his teeth, closing his eyes, shaking as if nauseated.

ɪɾɝɑldi sæɾ əpɹaɪt, sʌɾənli əlɝt, hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. pɔɪzən? wɑz ðə mæn wundəd?

Ituralde sat upright, suddenly alert, hand on his sword. Poison? Was the man wounded?

bʌt noʊ, ælθɹ oʊpən ɪz aɪz, ən ðəɹ sim tə bi ə lʊk ʌv ɛkstəsi ɪn ðoʊz dɛpθs. hi tɝnd, weɪvɪŋ ɪz hænd, ən ə laɪn ə laɪt splɪt ði ɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. mɛn ɝaʊn ɪɾɝɑldi kɝst, bækɪŋ ʌp. ɪt wɑz wʌn θɪŋ fəɹ ə mæn tə kleɪm i kəd tʃænəl; ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ tə si hɪm də soʊ ɪn fɹʌn ə ju!

But no, al'Thor opened his eyes, and there seemed to be a look of ecstasy in those depths. He turned, waving his hand, and a line of light split the air in front of him. Men around Ituralde cursed, backing up. It was one thing for a man to claim he could channel; it was another to see him do so in front of you!

"ðæts ə ɡeɪtweɪ," ælθɹ sɛɾ əz ðə laɪn ə laɪt tɝn ɝaʊnd, oʊpənɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ blæk hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ. "dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ði æʃəmənz stʃɹɛŋkθ, ə ɡeɪtweɪ kən bi meɪd waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹaɪv wæɡənz θɹu. jə kən tʃɹævəl nɪɹli ɛniwɛɹ wɪð spid, səmtaɪmz ɪnstənli, dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn sɝkəmstænsəz. wɪð ə fju tʃɹeɪn æʃəmən, jəɹ ɑɹmi kəd daɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, ðən əv lʌntʃ ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ə fju aʊɝz leɪɾɝ."

"That's a gateway," al'Thor said as the line of light turned around, opening a large black hole in the air. "Depending on the Asha'man's strength, a gateway can be made wide enough to drive wagons through. You can travel nearly anywhere with speed, sometimes instantly, depending on circumstances. With a few trained Asha'man, your army could dine in Caemlyn in the morning, then have lunch in Tanchico a few hours later."

ɪɾɝɑldi ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn. "wɛl naʊ, ðæts ə θɪŋ tə si. ə θɪŋ tə si ɪndid." ɪf ðɪs mæn spoʊk tʃɹuθfəli, ən ðiz ɡeɪtweɪz ɹɪli dɪd wɝk. . . . "wɪð ðɪs aɪ kəd klɪɹ ðə sintʃæn aʊɾ ə tæɹɑbən, ən meɪbi ɔf ðə læn ɪntaɪɝli!"

Ituralde rubbed his chin. "Well now, that's a thing to see. A thing to see indeed." If this man spoke truthfully, and these gateways really did work. . . . "With this I could clear the Seanchan out of Tarabon, and maybe off the land entirely!"

"noʊ," ælθɹ snæpt. "wi meɪk pis wɪð ðɛm. fɹəm wʌt maɪ skaʊts seɪ, ɪts gɑnə bi hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə bɹɪŋ əm tə əɡɹimənt wɪθaʊt pɹɑməsɪŋ əm jəɹ hɛd. aɪ woʊn ɹaɪl əm fɝðɝ.

"No," al'Thor snapped. "We make peace with them. From what my scouts say, it's going to be hard enough to bring them to agreement without promising them your head. I won't rile them further.

ðəɹ ɪz noʊ taɪm fəɹ skwɑbəlɪŋ. wɪv mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz tə bi əbaʊt."

There is no time for squabbling. We have more important matters to be about."

"nʌθɪŋ ɪz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən maɪ hoʊmlænd," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. "ivən ɪf ðoʊz ɔɹɾɝz ɑɹ fɔɹdʒd, aɪ noʊ ælsələm. hi wəɾ əɡɹi wɪð mi. wi woʊn stæn fəɹ fɔɹən tʃɹups ɑn ðə sɔɪl ʌv ɑɹæd dumən."

"Nothing is more important than my homeland," Ituralde said. "Even if those orders are forged, I know Alsalam. He would agree with me. We won't stand for foreign troops on the soil of Arad Doman."

"ə pɹɑməs, ðɛn," ælθɹ sɛd. "aɪ wɪl si ðə sintʃæn aʊɾ ʌv ɑɹæd dumən. aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðɪs.

"A promise, then," al'Thor said. "I will see the Seanchan out of Arad Doman. I promise you this.

bʌt wi doʊn faɪɾ əm əweɪ ɛni fɝðɝ ðən ðæt. ɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒ, jə ɡoʊ tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz ən pɹətɛkt əɡɛnst ən ɪnveɪʒən ðɛɹ. hoʊl bæk ðə tʃɹɑləks ɪf ðeɪ kʌm, ən lɛn mi səm ə jəɹ ɔfəsɝz tə hɛlp sɪkjʊɹ ɑɹæd dumən. ɪɾəl bi iziɝ tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ ɪf ðə pipəl si ðət ðɛɹ oʊn lɔɹdz ɑɹ wɝkɪŋ wɪð mi."

But we don't fight them away any further than that. In exchange, you go to the Borderlands and protect against an invasion there. Hold back the Trollocs if they come, and lend me some of your officers to help secure Arad Doman. It will be easier to restore order if the people see that their own lords are working with me."

ɪɾɝɑldi kənsɪɾɝd, ðoʊ hi nu ɔlɹɛɾi wʌɾ ɪz ænsɝ wəd bi. ðət ɡeɪtweɪ kəd spɪɹəɾ ɪz mɛn əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs dɛθ tʃɹæp. wɪð il ɑn ɪz saɪd - wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz ən ælaɪ - hi ɹɪli dɪɾ əv ə tʃæns ə kipɪŋ ɑɹæd dumən sɪkjʊɹ. ən ɑnɝəbəl dɛθ wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ. bʌt ði əbɪləɾi tə kip ɑn faɪɾɪŋ wɪð ɑnɝ . . . ðət wɑz ə pɹaɪz fɑɹ mɔɹ pɹɛʃəs.

Ituralde considered, though he knew already what his answer would be. That gateway could spirit his men away from this death trap. With Aiel on his side - with the Dragon Reborn as an ally - he really did have a chance of keeping Arad Doman secure. An honorable death was a good thing. But the ability to keep on fighting with honor . . . that was a prize far more precious.

"əɡɹid," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ə hænd.

"Agreed," Ituralde said, holding out a hand.

ælθɹ tʊk ɪt. "ɡoʊ bɹeɪk kæmp. jəɹ tə bi ɪn sɑldɑiə baɪ naɪtfɔl."

Al'Thor took it. "Go break camp. You're to be in Saldaea by nightfall."

tʃæptɝ ɪlɛvən

CHAPTER 11

ðə dɛθ ʌv ɑdʒɹɪn aɪ θɪŋk i ʃəd bi biɾən əɡɛn, sɛd lɹiən, muvɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪn ðə kɑmplɛks moʊʃənz ə meɪɾən hæntɔk. hiz laɪk ə tʃaɪld, ən wən ə tʃaɪl tʌtʃəz sʌmθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs, ðə tʃaɪld ɪz biɾən. ɪf ə tʃaɪl hɝts hɪmsɛlf kəz i wɑz nɑt tɔt pɹɑpɝli tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm naɪvz, ðən ðə ʃeɪm ɪz əpɑn ɪz pɛɹəns.

The Death of Adrin I think he should be beaten again, said Lerian, moving her fingers in the complex motions of Maiden handtalk. He is like a child, and when a child touches something dangerous, the child is beaten. If a child hurts himself because he was not taught properly to stay away from knives, then the shame is upon his parents.

ðə pɹiviəs biɾɪŋ dɪd nɑt sim tə də ɛni ɡʊd, sʊɹiəl ɹɪplaɪd. hi æksɛptɪɾ ɪt laɪk ə mæn, nɑɾ ə tʃaɪld, bʌt dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ɪz ækʃənz.

The previous beating did not seem to do any good, Surial replied. He accepted it like a man, not a child, but did not change his actions.

ðən wi mʌs tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn, lɹiən ɹɪplaɪd.

Then we must try again, Lerian replied.

eɪvinhə dʒɹɑpt əɹ ɹɑk ɪndə ðə paɪl baɪ ðə wɑtʃpoʊst, ðən tɝn ɝaʊnd. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ æknɑlɪdʒ ðə meɪɾənz u wɑtʃt ðə weɪ ɪndə ðə kæmp, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ æknɑlɪdʒ hɝ.

Aviendha dropped her rock into the pile by the watchpost, then turned around. She did not acknowledge the Maidens who watched the way into the camp, and they did not acknowledge her.

spikɪŋ tə hɝ waɪl ʃi wɑz biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt wəɾ oʊnli haɪɾən əɹ ʃeɪm, ən əɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz wəd nɑt də ðæt.

Speaking to her while she was being punished would only heighten her shame, and her spear-sisters would not do that.

ʃi ɔlsoʊ dɪdn ɪndəkeɪt ðət ʃi ʌndɝstʊd ðɛɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən. waɪl noʊbɑdi ɪkspɛktəɾ ə fɔɹmɝ meɪɾən tə fɝɡɛt hæntɔk, ɪt wɑz bɛs tə bi ʌnəbtʃɹusɪv. ðə hæntɔk bɪlɔŋ tə ðə meɪɾənz.

She also didn't indicate that she understood their conversation. While nobody expected a former Maiden to forget handtalk, it was best to be unobtrusive. The handtalk belonged to the Maidens.

eɪvinhə səlɛktəɾ ə lɑɹdʒ stoʊn fɹəm ə sɛkən paɪl, ðən bɪɡæn tə wɔk bæk ɪndə kæmp. ɪf ðə meɪɾənz kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən, ʃi kəd nɑt tɛl, əz ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ si ðɛɹ hænz. bʌt ðɛɹ dɪskʌʃən lɪŋɡɝd wɪð hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ æŋɡɝd ðət ɹænd ælθɹ hæd ɡɔn tə mit wɪð ðə dʒɛnɝəl ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi wɪθaʊt ɡɑɹdz. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm i hæɾ æktəd soʊ fulɪʃli, ən jɛɾ i simd ənwɪlɪŋ - əɹ əneɪbəl - tə lɝn ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪ. itʃ taɪm i pʊt hɪmsɛlf ɪn deɪnʒɝ wɪθaʊt pɹətɛkʃən, hi ɪnsʌltɪd ðə meɪɾənz əz ʃʊɹli əz ɪf i hæd slæpt itʃ wʌn ɪn ðə feɪs.

Aviendha selected a large stone from a second pile, then began to walk back into camp. If the Maidens continued their conversation, she could not tell, as she could no longer see their hands. But their discussion lingered with her. They were angered that Rand al'Thor had gone to meet with the general Rodel Ituralde without guards. It was not the first time he had acted so foolishly, and yet he seemed unwilling - or unable - to learn the proper way. Each time he put himself in danger without protection, he insulted the Maidens as surely as if he had slapped each one in the face.

eɪvinhə pɹɑbli hæd səm smɔl toʊ təwɔɹɾ əɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz. titʃɪŋ ɹænd ælθɹ ʌv il weɪz hæd bɪn əɹ tæsk, ən ʃi hæd kwaɪɾ ɑbviəsli feɪld. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi hæɾ ə mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪɾɝ toʊ təwɔɹd ðə waɪz wʌnz, ivən ɪf ʃi stɪl dɪdnt noʊ ðə ɹizən. hɝ lɛsɝ duɾi tə hɝ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz wəɾ əv tə weɪt fəɹ ən əpɹoʊpɹiət taɪm.

Aviendha probably had some small toh toward her spear-sisters. Teaching Rand al'Thor of Aiel ways had been her task, and she had quite obviously failed. Unfortunately, she had a much greater toh toward the Wise Ones, even if she still didn't know the reason. Her lesser duty to her spear-sisters would have to wait for an appropriate time.

hɝ ɑɹmz ætʃt fɹəm kæɹiɪŋ ɹɑks. ðeɪ wɝ smuð ən hɛvi; ʃi hæd bɪn ɹikwaɪɝd tə dɪɡ ðɛm aʊɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ bɪsaɪd ðə mænɝ haʊs. oʊnli hɝ taɪm spɛnt wɪð ɪleɪn - wən ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə beɪð ɪn wɔɾɝ - hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə wɔk ɪndə ðət ɹɪvɝ. ɪn ðæt, ʃi hæd nɑt ʃeɪm hɝsɛlf. ən ət lis ðɪs ɹɪvɝ wɑz ə smɔl wʌn - wɛtləndɝz maɪɾ ɪnækjɝətli kɔl ɪɾ ə stʃɹim. ə stʃɹim wɑz ə taɪni maʊntən ɹʌnɔf ɪn wɪtʃ jə kəd dɪp jəɹ hænz əɹ fɪl ə wɔɾɝskɪn.

Her arms ached from carrying rocks. They were smooth and heavy; she had been required to dig them out of the river beside the manor house. Only her time spent with Elayne - when she had been forced to bathe in water - had given her the strength to walk into that river. In that, she had not shamed herself. And at least this river was a small one - wetlanders might inaccurately call it a stream. A stream was a tiny mountain runoff in which you could dip your hands or fill a waterskin.

ɛniθɪŋ tu lɑɹdʒ tə stɛp əkɹɔs wɑz dɛfənətli ə ɹɪvɝ.

Anything too large to step across was definitely a river.

ðə deɪ wɑz oʊvɝkæst, əz juʒəwəl, ən ðə kæmp wɑz səbdud. mɛn u hæd bʌsəl dʒʌs deɪz bɪfɔɹ - wən ði il hæɾ ɝaɪvd - wɝ mɔɹ ləθɑɹdʒɪk naʊ. ðə kæmp wɑzn baɪ ɛni minz ənkɛmpt; dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ wɑz tu kɛɹfəl ə kəmændɝ tə əlaʊ ðæt, wɛtləndɝ ðoʊ hi wɑz.

The day was overcast, as usual, and the camp was subdued. Men who had bustled just days before - when the Aiel had arrived - were more lethargic now. The camp wasn't by any means unkempt; Davram Bashere was too careful a commander to allow that, wetlander though he was.

haʊɛvɝ, ðə mɛn dɪd muv mɔɹ sloʊli. ʃi hæd hɝd səm ə ðɛm kəmpleɪn ðət ðə dɑɹk skaɪ wɑz dæmpənɪŋ ðɛɹ mudz. haʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ wɛtləndɝz wɝ! wʌd ðə wɛðɝ əv tə də wɪð wʌnz mud? ʃi kəɾ ʌndɝstæn biɪŋ dɪspliz ðət noʊ ɹeɪdz wɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, əɹ ðəɾ ə hʌn hæd ɡɔn pʊɹli. bʌt kəz ðəɹ wɝ klaʊdz ɪn ðə skaɪ? wɑz ʃeɪd soʊ pʊɹli əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd hɪɹ?

However, the men did move more slowly. She had heard some of them complain that the dark sky was dampening their moods. How strange wetlanders were! What did the weather have to do with one's mood? She could understand being displeased that no raids were approaching, or that a hunt had gone poorly. But because there were clouds in the sky? Was shade so poorly appreciated here?

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ ɑn əɹ weɪ. ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən stoʊnz wɪtʃ wəd stʃɹeɪn əɹ mʌsəlz. tə də ʌðɝwaɪz wʊɾə bɪn tə meɪk laɪɾ ə hɝ pʌnɪʃmənt, ən ʃi wʊdn də ðæt  - ɔlðoʊ itʃ stɛp peɪn əɹ ɑnɝ. ʃi hæd tə kɹɔs θɹu ði ɪntaɪɝ kæmp, ɪn fʊl saɪt, duɪŋ wɝk ðət wɑz jusləs! ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ əv bɪn neɪkəd bɪfɔɹ əm ɔl aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə swɛt tɛnt.

She shook her head, continuing on her way. She had chosen stones which would strain her muscles. To do otherwise would have been to make light of her punishment, and she wouldn't do that  - although each step pained her honor. She had to cross through the entire camp, in full sight, doing work that was useless! She would rather have been naked before them all outside of the sweat tent.

ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ əv ɹʌn ə θaʊzən læps, əɹ bɪn biɾən soʊ hɑɹd ðət ʃi kʊdnt wɔk.

She would rather have run a thousand laps, or been beaten so hard that she couldn't walk.

ʃi ɹitʃt ðə saɪɾ ə ðə mænɝ haʊs ən dəpɑzɪɾɪd əɹ stoʊn wɪð ə hɪɾən saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. tu wɛtləndɝ soʊlʒɝz fɹəm bæʃɪɹz ɑɹmi stʊd ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə dɔɹ ɪndə ðə mænɝ, ə kaʊntɝpɑɹt tə ðə tu meɪɾənz ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ʌv eɪvinhəz tʃɹɛk. əz ʃi stupt ən pɪkt ʌp ə lɑɹdʒ stoʊn fɹəm ə sɛkən paɪl baɪ ðə wɔl, ʃi oʊvɝhɝɾ əm spikɪŋ.

She reached the side of the manor house and deposited her stone with a hidden sigh of relief. Two wetlander soldiers from Bashere's army stood guarding the door into the manor, a counterpart to the two Maidens at the other end of Aviendha's trek. As she stooped and picked up a large stone from a second pile by the wall, she overheard them speaking.

"bɝn mi, bʌɾ ɪts hɑt," wʌn ə ðə mɛn kəmpleɪnd.

"Burn me, but it's hot," one of the men complained.

"hɑt?" ði ʌðɝ ɹɪplaɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ. "jɔɹ dʒɛstɪŋ."

"Hot?" the other replied, glancing at the overcast sky. "You're jesting."

ðə fɝst ɡɑɹd weɪvd ɪz hæn ət hɪmsɛlf, pʌfɪŋ aʊɾ ən swɛɾɪŋ. "haʊ kən jə nɑt fil ðæt?"

The first guard waved his hand at himself, puffing out and sweating. "How can you not feel that?"

"ju mʌst əv ə fivɝ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ."

"You must have a fever or something."

ðə fɝst ɡɑɹd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ dʒʌs doʊn laɪk ðə hit, ðæts ɔl."

The first guard shook his head. "I just don't like the heat, that's all."

eɪvinhə pɪkt ʌp əɹ ɹɑk ən bɪɡæn tə wɔk bæk əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹin. æftɝ səm kɑntəmpleɪʃən, ʃi hæd dɪtɝmən ðət biɪŋ ə wɛtləndɝ ɹikwaɪɝd wʌn kɑmən ətʃɹɪbjut: ə fɑndnəs fəɹ kəmpleɪnɪŋ. dʊɹɪŋ əɹ fɝs mʌnθs ɪn ðə wɛtlænz, ʃi hæd kənsɪɾɝd ðɪs ʃeɪmfəl. dɪd ðət ɡɑɹd nɑt kɛɹ ðəɾ i wɑz luzɪŋ feɪs ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz fɛloʊ baɪ ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ɪz wiknəs?

Aviendha picked up her rock and began to walk back across the green. After some contemplation, she had determined that being a wetlander required one common attribute: a fondness for complaining. During her first months in the wetlands, she had considered this shameful. Did that guard not care that he was losing face in front of his fellow by exposing his weakness?

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl laɪk ðæt, ivən ɪleɪn. ɪf jə lɪsən tə hɝ tɔk əbaʊt ði eɪks, sɪknəsəz ən fɹəstʃɹeɪʃənz ə hɝ pɹɛɡnənsi, jə wəɾ ɔlmoʊs θɪŋk ʃi wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ dɛθ! haʊɛvɝ, ɪf kəmpleɪnɪŋ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪleɪn dɪd, ðən eɪvinhə ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɪɾ əz ə saɪn ʌv wiknəs.

They were all like that, even Elayne. If you listened to her talk about the aches, sicknesses and frustrations of her pregnancy, you would almost think she was approaching death! However, if complaining was something that Elayne did, then Aviendha refused to accept it as a sign of weakness.

hɝ fɝst-sɪstɝ wəd nɑɾ ækt ɪn sətʃ ə ʃeɪmfəl weɪ.

Her first-sister would not act in such a shameful way.

ðɛɹfɔɹ, ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm hɪɾən ɑnɝ ɪn ɪt. pɝhæps ðə wɛtləndɝz ɪkspoʊz ðɛɹ wiknəsəz tə ðɛɹ kəmpænjənz əz ə minz ʌv ɔfɝɪŋ fɹɛndʃɪp ən tʃɹʌst. ɪf jəɹ fɹɛnz nu ʌv jəɹ wiknəsəz, ɪt wəd ɡɪv əm ən ædvæntɪdʒ ʃəd jə dæns ðə spɪɹz wɪð ðɛm. ɔɹ, pɝhæps, ðə kəmpleɪnɪŋ wɑz ə wɛtləndɝ weɪ ʌv ʃoʊɪŋ hjumɪlɪɾi, mʌtʃ əz ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn ʃoʊɾ ɑnɝ baɪ biɪŋ səbsɝviənt.

Therefore, there had to be some hidden honor in it. Perhaps the wetlanders exposed their weaknesses to their companions as a means of offering friendship and trust. If your friends knew of your weaknesses, it would give them an advantage should you dance the spears with them. Or, perhaps, the complaining was a wetlander way of showing humility, much as the gai'shain showed honor by being subservient.

ʃi hæɾ æskt ɪleɪn əbaʊɾ əɹ θɪɹiz ən hæd ɹəsivd oʊnli ə fɑn læf ɪn ɹɪtɝn. wɑz ɪt səm æspɛkt ʌv wɛtləndɝ səsaɪəɾi ðət ʃi wɑz fɔɹbɪɾən tə dɪskʌs wɪð aʊtsaɪɾɝz, ðɛn? hæɾ ɪleɪn læf kəz eɪvinhə hæd fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt sʌmθɪŋ ʃi wɑz nɑt mɛn tə?

She had asked Elayne about her theories and had received only a fond laugh in return. Was it some aspect of wetlander society that she was forbidden to discuss with outsiders, then? Had Elayne laughed because Aviendha had figured out something she was not meant to?

iðɝ weɪ, ɪt wɑz sɝɾənli ə weɪ tə ʃoʊ ɑnɝ, ən ðət sæɾəsfaɪd eɪvinhə. ɪf oʊnli hɝ oʊn pɹɑbləmz wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ əz sɪmpəl! ɪt wɑz ɪkspɛktəd ðət ðə wɛtləndɝz wəɾ ækt ɪn ɪɹæɾɪk, ənnætʃɹəl weɪz. bʌt wʌt wɑz ʃi tə də wən waɪz wʌnz bɪheɪv soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒli?

Either way, it was certainly a way to show honor, and that satisfied Aviendha. If only her own problems with the Wise Ones were as simple! It was expected that the wetlanders would act in erratic, unnatural ways. But what was she to do when Wise Ones behaved so strangely?

ʃi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd - nɑt wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz, bʌt wɪð hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ən bɹeɪv.

She was growing frustrated - not with the Wise Ones, but with herself. She was strong and brave.

nɑɾ əz bɹeɪv əz səm ʌðɝz, ʌv kɔɹs; ʃi kəɾ oʊnli wɪʃ tə bi əz boʊld əz ɪleɪn. stɪl, eɪvinhə kəd θɪŋk ʌv oʊnli ə fju pɹɑbləmz wɪtʃ ʃi hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə sɑlv wɪð ði æpləkeɪʃən ə spɪɹz, ðə wʌn paʊɝ əɹ əɹ wɪts. jɛt ʃi hæd feɪld ʌɾɝli ət dəsaɪfɝɪŋ əɹ kɝən pɹɪdɪkəmənt.
