Not as brave as some others, of course; she could only wish to be as bold as Elayne. Still, Aviendha could think of only a few problems which she hadn't been able to solve with the application of spears, the One Power or her wits. Yet she had failed utterly at deciphering her current predicament.

ʃi ɹitʃt ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp ən dəpɑzɪɾɪd əɹ stoʊn, ðən bɹʌʃt ɔf əɹ hænz. ðə meɪɾənz stʊd moʊʃənləs ən kəntɛmpləɾɪv. eɪvinhə muv tə ði ʌðɝ paɪl ən pɪkt ʌp ən ɑblɔŋ ɹɑk wɪð ə dʒæɡd ɛdʒ. ɪt wɑz θɹi hændspænz waɪd, ən ðə smuð sɝfəs θɹɛɾənd tə slɪp ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ʃi hæd tə ʃɪft ɪt sɛvɹəl taɪmz bɪfɔɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ə ɡʊd pɝtʃəs. ʃi hɛɾəd bæk əkɹɔs ðə tʃɹæmpəld wɪntɝ θætʃ, pæst sɑldəiən tɛns, təwɔɹd ðə mænɝ haʊs.

She reached the other side of the camp and deposited her stone, then brushed off her hands. The Maidens stood motionless and contemplative. Aviendha moved to the other pile and picked up an oblong rock with a jagged edge. It was three handspans wide, and the smooth surface threatened to slip in her fingers. She had to shift it several times before getting a good purchase. She headed back across the trampled winter thatch, past Saldaean tents, toward the manor house.

ɪleɪn wəd seɪ ðəɾ eɪvinhə hædn θɔt ðə pɹɑbləm θɹu. ɪleɪn wɑz kɑm ən θɔtfəl wən ʌðɝ pipəl wɝ tɛns. eɪvinhə səmtaɪmz ɡɹu fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd wɪð haʊ mʌtʃ əɹ fɝst-sɪstɝ laɪk tə tɔk bɪfɔɹ kəmɪɾɪŋ tə ækʃən. aɪ nid tə bi mɔɹ laɪk hɝ. aɪ nid tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ aɪm nɑɾ ə meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. aɪ kæn tʃɑɹdʒ ɪn wɪð wɛpən hɛl haɪ.

Elayne would say that Aviendha hadn't thought the problem through. Elayne was calm and thoughtful when other people were tense. Aviendha sometimes grew frustrated with how much her first-sister liked to talk before committing to action. I need to be more like her. I need to remember that I'm not a Maiden of the Spear any longer. I can't charge in with weapon held high.

ʃi niɾəd tə əpɹoʊtʃ pɹɑbləmz əz ɪleɪn dɪd. ðət wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ ʃi wɑz gɑnə ɡɛɾ əɹ ɑnɝ bæk, ən oʊnli ðən kəd ʃi kleɪm ɹænd ælθɹ ən meɪk ɪm hɝz əz mʌtʃ əz i wɑz ɪleɪnz əɹ mɪnz. ʃi kəd fil ɪm θɹu ðə bɑnd; hi wɑz ɪn ɪz ɹum, bʌt wɑz nɑt slipɪŋ. hi pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf hɑɹɾ ən slɛp tu lɪɾəl.

She needed to approach problems as Elayne did. That was the only way she was going to get her honor back, and only then could she claim Rand al'Thor and make him hers as much as he was Elayne's or Min's. She could feel him through the bond; he was in his room, but was not sleeping. He pushed himself hard and slept too little.

ðə stoʊn slɪpt ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ən ʃi nɪɹli stʌmbəld əz ʃi ɹibælənst əɹ weɪt, hɛftɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn taɪɝɾ ɑɹmz. səm ə bæʃɪɹz soʊlʒɝz wɔk pæst, bɪmjuzd ɪkspɹɛʃənz ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ən eɪvinhə fɛl hɝsɛlf blʌʃ. ɔlðoʊ ðeɪ maɪt nɑt noʊ ðət ʃi wɑz biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt, ʃi wɑz ʃeɪm bɪfɔɹ ðɛm.

The stone slipped in her fingers, and she nearly stumbled as she rebalanced her weight, hefting it in tired arms. Some of Bashere's soldiers walked past, bemused expressions on their faces, and Aviendha felt herself blush. Although they might not know that she was being punished, she was shamed before them.

haʊ wəɾ ɪleɪn ɹizən aʊt ðɪs sɪtʃueɪʃən? ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ æŋɡɹi əɾ eɪvinhə fəɹ nɑt "lɝnɪŋ kwɪkli ɪnʌf." ən jɛt ðeɪ dɪdn titʃ hɝ. ðeɪ dʒʌst æsk ðoʊz kwɛstʃənz. kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðɛɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən, kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ɹænd ælθɹ əɹ əbaʊt ðə weɪ ɹəɑɹk hæd hændəl miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn.

How would Elayne reason out this situation? The Wise Ones were angry at Aviendha for not "learning quickly enough." And yet they didn't teach her. They just asked those questions. Questions about what she thought of their situation, questions about Rand al'Thor or about the way Rhuarc had handled meeting with the Car'a'carn.

eɪvinhə kʊdn hɛlp filɪŋ ðət ðə kwɛstʃənz wɝ tɛsts. wɑz ʃi ænsɝɪŋ ɪnkɝɛkli? ɪf soʊ, waɪ dɪdn ðeɪ ɪnstʃɹʌkt əɹ ɪn ðə pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɑnsɪz?

Aviendha couldn't help feeling that the questions were tests. Was she answering incorrectly? If so, why didn't they instruct her in the proper responses?

ðə waɪz wʌnz dɪdn θɪŋk ʃi wɑz sɑft. wʌt wɑz lɛft? wʌt wəɾ ɪleɪn seɪ? eɪvinhə wɪʃt fəɹ əɹ spɪɹz bæk soʊ ðət ʃi kəd stæb sʌmθɪŋ. ətæk, tɛs hɝsɛlf əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ, wɝk aʊɾ əɹ æŋɡɝ.

The Wise Ones didn't think she was soft. What was left? What would Elayne say? Aviendha wished for her spears back so that she could stab something. Attack, test herself against another, work out her anger.

noʊ, ʃi θɔt fɔɹsfəli. aɪm gɑnə lɝn tə də ðɪs əz ə waɪz wʌn. əl faɪn ɑnɝ əɡɛn!

No, she thought forcefully. I am going to learn to do this as a Wise One. I will find honor again!

ʃi ɹitʃt ðə mænɝ ən dʒɹɑpt əɹ ɹɑk. ʃi waɪpt əɹ bɹaʊ; ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ hiɾ ən koʊld əz ɪleɪn hæd tɔɾ əɹ dɪdn kip əɹ fɹəm swɛɾɪŋ wən ʃi wɝkt əɹ bɑɾi ðɪs hɑɹd.

She reached the manor and dropped her rock. She wiped her brow; ignoring heat and cold as Elayne had taught her didn't keep her from sweating when she worked her body this hard.

"ɑdʒɹɪn?" wʌn dɔɹ ɡɑɹɾ æskt ɪz kəmpænjən. "laɪt, jə doʊn lʊk wɛl. tʃɹuli."

"Adrin?" one door guard asked his companion. "Light, you don't look well. Truly."

eɪvinhə ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹweɪ ɪndə ðə mænɝ. ðə ɡɑɹɾ u hæd bɪn kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊt ðə hit wɑz sæɡɪŋ əɡɛns ðə dɔɹweɪ, hæn ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. hi ɹɪli dɪdn lʊk wɛl.

Aviendha glanced toward the doorway into the manor. The guard who had been complaining about the heat was sagging against the doorway, hand on his forehead. He really didn't look well.

eɪvinhə ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ. ʃi wɑzn ðə bɛst ət hilɪŋ, bʌt pɝhæps ʃi kəd -  ðə mæn ɹitʃt ʌp sʌɾənli, skɹætʃɪŋ ət ðə skɪn ə hɪz tɛmpəlz. hɪz aɪz ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn ɪz hɛɾ ən ɪz fɪŋɡɝz tɔɹ ɡæʃəz ɪn ɪz flɛʃ. oʊnli, ɪnstɛɾ ə blʌd, ðə wunz spæɾ aʊɾ ə blæk tʃɑɹkoʊl- laɪk sʌbstəns. eɪvinhə kəd fil ði ɪntɛns hiɾ ivən fɹəm ə dɪstəns.

Aviendha embraced saidar. She wasn't the best at Healing, but perhaps she could -  The man reached up suddenly, scratching at the skin of his temples. His eyes rolled up in his head and his fingers tore gashes in his flesh. Only, instead of blood, the wounds spat out a black charcoal- like substance. Aviendha could feel the intense heat even from a distance.

ði ʌðɝ ɡɑɹd ɡeɪpt ɪn hɔɹɝ əz ɪz fɹɛn ɹɪp laɪnz ə blæk faɪɝ daʊn ðə saɪdz ə hɪz hɛd. ə blækɪʃ tɑɹ uzd aʊt, bɔɪlɪŋ ən hɪsɪŋ. ðə mænz kloʊðɪŋ bɝst ɪndə fleɪmz ən ɪz flɛʃ ʃɹɪvəl fɹəm ðə hit.

The other guard gaped in horror as his friend ripped lines of black fire down the sides of his head. A blackish tar oozed out, boiling and hissing. The man's clothing burst into flames and his flesh shriveled from the heat.

hi dɪdn ʌɾɝ ə saʊnd.

He didn't utter a sound.

eɪvinhə ʃɹʌɡd ɔf əɹ ʃɑk, ɪmiɾiətli wivɪŋ ɛɹ ɪn ə sɪmpəl pæɾɝn tə pʊl ði ʌnəfɛktɪd ɡɑɹd tə seɪfti. hɪz fɹɛnd wɑz naʊ dʒʌst ə pʌlsɪŋ maʊn ə blæk tɑɹ wɪtʃ, ɪn pleɪsəz, spɹaʊɾəd blækən boʊnz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ skʌl. ðə hit wɑz soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðəɾ eɪvinhə hæd tə bæk əweɪ, pʊlɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹd wɪð hɝ.

Aviendha shrugged off her shock, immediately weaving Air in a simple pattern to pull the unaffected guard to safety. His friend was now just a pulsing mound of black tar which, in places, sprouted blackened bones. There was no skull. The heat was so strong that Aviendha had to back away, pulling the guard with her.

"wi . . . wɝ biɪŋ ətækt!" ðə mæn wɪspɝd. "tʃænlɝz!"

"We . . . we're being attacked!" the man whispered. "Channelers!"

"noʊ," eɪvinhə sɛd, "ðɪs ɪz sʌmθɪŋ fɑɹ mɔɹ ivəl. ɹʌn fəɹ hɛlp!"

"No," Aviendha said, "this is something far more evil. Run for help!"

hi sim tu ʃɑk tə muv, bʌt ʃi ʃʌvd ɪm ɪndə moʊʃən ən i bɪɡæn tə muv. ðə tɑɹ ɪtsɛlf dɪdn sim tə bi spɹɛɾɪŋ, wɪtʃ wɑz ə blɛsɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪɡnaɪɾɪd ðə dɔɹfɹeɪm ə ðə mænɝ. ɪt kəɾ əv ði ɪntaɪɝ bɪldɪŋ ɪn fleɪmz bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɪnsaɪd wɑz əwɛɹ ə ðə deɪnʒɝ.

He seemed too shocked to move, but she shoved him into motion and he began to move. The tar itself didn't seem to be spreading, which was a blessing, but it had already ignited the doorframe of the manor. It could have the entire building in flames before anyone inside was aware of the danger.

eɪvinhə woʊv ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ, ɪntɛndɪŋ tə ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃ ðə fleɪm. haʊɛvɝ, hɝ wivz fɹæzəld ən weɪvɝd wən ðeɪ ɡɑt nɪɹ ðə faɪɝ. ðeɪ dɪdn ənwiv, bʌt ðɪs faɪɝ sʌmhaʊ ɹɪzɪstɪd ðɛm.

Aviendha wove Air and Water, intending to extinguish the flame. However, her weaves frazzled and wavered when they got near the fire. They didn't unweave, but this fire somehow resisted them.

ʃi tʊk ənʌðɝ stɛp bæk fɹəm ði ɑsəm, bɝnɪŋ ɪntɛnsəɾi. hɝ bɹaʊ pɹɪkəld wɪð swɛt, ən ʃi hæd tə ɹeɪz əɹ ɑɹm tə ʃeɪɾ əɹ feɪs fɹəm ðə hit. ʃi kəd bɛɹli meɪk aʊt ðə blæk tʃɑɹ ət ðə sɛntɝ əz ɪt bɪɡæn tə ɡloʊ wɪð ðə dip ɹɛɾ ən waɪɾ ʌv ɪkstʃɹimli hɑt koʊlz. sun, oʊnli hɪns ə ðə blæk ɹɪmeɪnd. ðə faɪɝ spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ðə fɹʌnt wɔl ə ðə bɪldɪŋ. eɪvinhə hɝd skɹimz fɹəm ɪnsaɪd.

She took another step back from the awesome, burning intensity. Her brow prickled with sweat, and she had to raise her arm to shade her face from the heat. She could barely make out the black char at the center as it began to glow with the deep red and white of extremely hot coals. Soon, only hints of the black remained. The fire spread across the front wall of the building. Aviendha heard screams from inside.

eɪvinhə ʃʊk hɝsɛlf, ðən ɡɹaʊld ən woʊv ɝθ ən ɛɹ, pʊlɪŋ tʃʌŋks ə ðə ɡɹaʊn ʌp ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi hɝl ðiz ət ðə faɪɝ, sikɪŋ tə smʌðɝ ɪt. hɝ wiv kəd nɑt dʒɹɔ ðə hiɾ aʊt, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt stɑp əɹ fɹəm juzɪŋ wivz tə kæst aɪɾəmz ɪndə ðə faɪɝ. tʃʌŋks ʌv ɡɹæs-kʌvɝɾ ɝθ sɪzəld ən hɪst, wɑn bleɪdz flæʃɪŋ tə æʃ bɪfɔɹ ði ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl hit. eɪvinhə kəntɪnjud tə wɝk, swɛɾɪŋ fɹəm boʊθ ði ɪɡzɝʃən ən ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝ.

Aviendha shook herself, then growled and wove Earth and Air, pulling chunks of the ground up around her. She hurled these at the fire, seeking to smother it. Her weave could not draw the heat out, but that did not stop her from using weaves to cast items into the fire. Chunks of grass-covered earth sizzled and hissed, wan blades flashing to ash before the incredible heat. Aviendha continued to work, sweating from both the exertion and the temperature.

ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ʃi hɝd pipəl - pɝhæps ðə ɡɑɹɾ əmʌŋ əm - kɔlɪŋ fəɹ bʌkəts.

In the distance, she heard people - perhaps the guard among them - calling for buckets.

bʌkəts? ʌv kɔɹs! ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd, wɔɾɝ wɑz fɑɹ tu væljəbəl tə juz ɪn faɪɾɪŋ faɪɝz.

Buckets? Of course! In the Three-fold Land, water was far too valuable to use in fighting fires.

dɝɾ əɹ sænd wɑz juzd. bʌt hɪɹ, ðeɪ wəd juz wɔɾɝ. eɪvinhə tʊk sɛvɹəl stɛps bækwɝd, sɝtʃɪŋ aʊt ðə kɝlɪŋ ɹɪvɝ ðət ɹæn bɪsaɪd ðə mænɝ. ʃi kəd dʒʌs bɛɹli meɪk aʊɾ ɪts sɝfəs, ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə dænsɪŋ ɹɛdz ən ɔɹənʒəz ə ðə fleɪmz. ɔlɹɛɾi, ði ɪntaɪɝ fɹʌn ə ðə mænɝ wɑz əfleɪm! ʃi fɛl tʃænəlɪŋ fɹəm ɪnsaɪd - ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ waɪz wʌnz. hoʊpfəli, ðeɪ wəɾ ɪskeɪp aʊɾ ə ðə bæk ə ðə bɪldɪŋ. ðə faɪɝ hæɾ ɪnɡʌlf ði ɪnɝ hɔlweɪ, ən ðə ɹumz ɔf ʌv ɪt hæd noʊ dɔɹz aʊt.

Dirt or sand was used. But here, they would use water. Aviendha took several steps backward, searching out the curling river that ran beside the manor. She could just barely make out its surface, reflecting the dancing reds and oranges of the flames. Already, the entire front of the manor was aflame! She felt channeling from inside - Aes Sedai or Wise Ones. Hopefully, they would escape out of the back of the building. The fire had engulfed the inner hallway, and the rooms off of it had no doors out.

eɪvinhə woʊv ə mæsɪv kɑləm ʌv ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ, pʊlɪŋ ə spaʊɾ ə kɹɪstəlaɪn lɪkwəd fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ən dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪt təwɔɹd hɝ. ðə kɑləm ʌv wɔɾɝ ənʒəleɪtɪd ɪn ði ɛɹ laɪk ðə kɹitʃɝ ɑn ɹændz bænɝ, ə ɡlæsi sɝpəntaɪn dʒɹæɡən ðət slæmd əɡɛns ðə fleɪmz. stim hɪst aʊtwɝɾ ɪn ən ɪksploʊʒən, wɑʃɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ.

Aviendha wove a massive column of Air and Water, pulling a spout of crystalline liquid from the river and drawing it toward her. The column of water undulated in the air like the creature on Rand's banner, a glassy serpentine dragon that slammed against the flames. Steam hissed outward in an explosion, washing over her.

ðə hit wɑz paʊɝfəl ən ðə weɪv ə stim skɔldɪɾ əɹ skɪn, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt bæk daʊn. ʃi pʊl mɔɹ wɔɾɝ, hɝlɪŋ ə θɪk kɑləm ʌv ɪɾ ət ðə dɑɹkən maʊnd, wɪtʃ ʃi kəɾ oʊnli dʒʌs meɪk aʊt θɹu ðə stim.

The heat was powerful and the wave of steam scalded her skin, but she did not back down. She pulled more water, hurling a thick column of it at the darkened mound, which she could only just make out through the steam.

ðət hit wɑz soʊ ɪntɛns! eɪvinhə stʌmbəl bækwɝɾ ə fju stɛps, ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə wɝk. ðən ðəɹ wɑz ə sʌɾən ɪksploʊʒən əz ənʌðɝ kɑləm ʌv wɔɾɝ bɝs fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ən slæmd ɪndə ðə faɪɝ. ðɪs, əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ oʊn, daɪvɝɾɪd nɪɹli ði ɪntaɪɝ floʊ ʌv ðə ɹɪvɝ. eɪvinhə blɪŋkt. ði ʌðɝ kɑləm wɑz biɪŋ dɝɛktəd baɪ wivz ʃi kəd nɑt si, bʌt ʃi dɪd noʊɾəs ə fɪɡjɝ stændɪŋ ɪn ə wɪndoʊ ʌp ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, hæn fɔɹwɝd, feɪs kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɪntɛnsli. nf, wʌn ə ɹændz æʃəmən. ɪt wɑz sɛɾ i wɑz pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli stʃɹɔŋ wɪð ɛɹ.

That heat was so intense! Aviendha stumbled backward a few steps, gritting her teeth, continuing to work. Then there was a sudden explosion as another column of water burst from the river and slammed into the fire. This, along with her own, diverted nearly the entire flow of the river. Aviendha blinked. The other column was being directed by weaves she could not see, but she did notice a figure standing in a window up on the second floor, hand forward, face concentrating intensely. Naeff, one of Rand's Asha'man. It was said he was particularly strong with Air.

ðə faɪɝz hæd ɹitʃɹiɾəd; oʊnli ðə tɛɹi maʊn ɹɪmeɪnd, ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ ə paʊɝfəl hit. ðə wɔl nɪɹ ɪɾ ən ði ɛntʃɹɪweɪ ɪnsaɪd hæd bɪkʌm ə ɡeɪpɪŋ, blækən hoʊl. eɪvinhə kəntɪnjud tə pʊl wɔɾɝ ən dʌmp ɪɾ ɑn ðə tʃɑɹd blæk mæs, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fil ɪkstʃɹimli taɪɝd. hænlɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ wɔɾɝ ɹikwaɪɝɾ əɹ tə tʃænəl ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ kəpæsəɾi.

The fires had retreated; only the tarry mound remained, radiating a powerful heat. The wall near it and the entryway inside had become a gaping, blackened hole. Aviendha continued to pull water and dump it on the charred black mass, though she was beginning to feel extremely tired. Handling so much water required her to channel almost to her capacity.

sun ðə wɔɾɝ stɑp hɪsɪŋ. eɪvinhə slækt əɹ floʊ, ðən lɛɾ ɪt dʒɹɪbəl tə ə stɑp. ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn əɹ wɑz ə wɛt, blækən dɪsɝeɪ ðət smɛl hɛvəli ʌv sɑɡi æʃ. bɪts ʌv wʊɾ ən tʃɑɹ floʊɾəd ɪn ðə mʌɾi wɔɾɝ, ən ðə hoʊlz wɛɹ ʃi hæd ɹɪpt ʌp ɝθ wɝ fɪld, meɪkɪŋ pulz. ʃi wɔk fɔɹwɝd hɛzɪɾəntli, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə lʌmp ðət wɑz ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə ði ənfɔɹtʃənət soʊlʒɝ. ɪt wɑz ɡlæsi ən blæk, laɪk əbsɪɾiən, ən ɪt spɑɹkəld wɛtli. ʃi pɪkt ʌp ə lɛŋθ ə sɪŋʒd wʊd - bɹoʊkən fɹəm ðə wɔl baɪ ðə fɔɹs ə hɝ wɔɾɝ kɑləm - ən poʊkt ət ðə mæs. ɪt wɑz hɑɹɾ ən fɝm.

Soon the water stopped hissing. Aviendha slacked her flow, then let it dribble to a stop. The ground around her was a wet, blackened disarray that smelled heavily of soggy ash. Bits of wood and char floated in the muddy water, and the holes where she had ripped up earth were filled, making pools. She walked forward hesitantly, inspecting the lump that was the remains of the unfortunate soldier. It was glassy and black, like obsidian, and it sparkled wetly. She picked up a length of singed wood - broken from the wall by the force of her water column - and poked at the mass. It was hard and firm.

"bɝn ju!" ə vɔɪs bɛloʊd. eɪvinhə lʊkt ʌp. ɹænd ælθɹ stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðə bɹoʊkən hoʊl ðət naʊ fɔɹm ðə fɹʌn ə ðə mænʃən. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə skaɪ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz fɪst. "aɪ æm ðə wʌn jə wɑnt! jəl əv jəɹ wɔɹ sun ɪnʌf!"

"Burn you!" a voice bellowed. Aviendha looked up. Rand al'Thor strode through the broken hole that now formed the front of the mansion. He stared at the sky, shaking his fist. "I am the one you want! You will have your war soon enough!"

"ɹænd," eɪvinhə sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli. soʊlʒɝz wɝ mɪlɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɡɹin, lʊkɪŋ kənsɝnd, əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ə bæɾəl. bɪwɪldɝd sɝvəns pikt aʊɾ ə ɹumz ɪnsaɪd ðə mænɝ. ði ɪntaɪɝ ɛpəsoʊd wɪð ðə fleɪmz hæd teɪkən lɛs ðən faɪv mɪnəts.

"Rand," Aviendha said hesitantly. Soldiers were milling about the green, looking concerned, as if expecting a battle. Bewildered servants peeked out of rooms inside the manor. The entire episode with the flames had taken less than five minutes.

"aɪ wɪl stɑp ju!" ɹænd ɹɔɹd, kɑzɪŋ kɔlz ə fɹaɪt fɹəm boʊθ sɝvəns ən soʊlʒɝz. "du jə hɪɹ mi! aɪm kʌmɪŋ fəɹ ju! doʊnt weɪs jəɹ paʊɝ! jəl niɾ ɪɾ əɡɛns mi!"

"I will stop you!" Rand roared, causing calls of fright from both servants and soldiers. "Do you hear me! I am coming for you! Don't waste your power! You will need it against me!"

"ɹænd!" eɪvinhə kɔld.

"Rand!" Aviendha called.

hi fɹoʊz, ðən lʊk daʊn ət hɝ, deɪzd. ʃi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz, ən ʃi kəd fil ɪz æŋɡɝ, ɔlmoʊst əz ʃid fɛl ði ɪntɛns fleɪmz dʒʌst ə ʃɔɹt taɪm bɪfɔɹ. hi tɝn ən stɔkt əweɪ, wɔkɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə bɪldɪŋ ən ʌp ðə blækənd wʊɾən stɛps.

He froze, then looked down at her, dazed. She met his eyes, and she could feel his anger, almost as she'd felt the intense flames just a short time before. He turned and stalked away, walking back into the building and up the blackened wooden steps.

"laɪt!" ən æŋkʃəs vɔɪs æskt. "dʌz ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ hæpən ɔfən wən hiz nɪɹ?"

"Light!" an anxious voice asked. "Does this sort of thing happen often when he is near?"

eɪvinhə tɝn tə si ə jʌŋ mæn ɪn ən ʌnfəmɪljɝ junəfɔɹm stændɪŋ ən wɑtʃɪŋ. hi wɑz læŋki, wɪð laɪt bɹaʊn hɛɹ ən kɑpɝi skɪn - ʃi dɪdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪz neɪm, bʌt ʃi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən i wɑz wʌn ə ði ɔfəsɝz ɹænd hæd bɹɔt bæk æftɝ miɾɪŋ wɪð ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi.

Aviendha turned to see a young man in an unfamiliar uniform standing and watching. He was lanky, with light brown hair and coppery skin - she didn't remember his name, but she was fairly certain he was one of the officers Rand had brought back after meeting with Rodel Ituralde.

ʃi tɝn bæk tə ðə mɛs, lɪsnɪŋ tə soʊlʒɝz kɔl ɔɹɾɝz ɪn ðə dɪstəns. bæʃɪɹ hæɾ ɝaɪvd ən wɑz teɪkɪŋ kəmænd, tɛlɪŋ mɛn tə wɑtʃ ðə pɝɪməɾɝ, ðoʊ hi wɑz laɪkli dʒʌst ɡɪvɪŋ əm sʌmθɪŋ tə du. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʌv ən ətæk. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃəz ɑn ðə wɝld, laɪk mit spɔɪlɪŋ, biɾəlz ən ɹæts əpɪɹɪŋ fɹəm nʌθɪŋ, ən mɛn dʒɹɑpɪŋ dɛɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ dɪzizəz.

She turned back to the mess, listening to soldiers call orders in the distance. Bashere had arrived and was taking command, telling men to watch the perimeter, though he was likely just giving them something to do. This was not the beginning of an attack. It was just another of the Dark One's touches on the world, like meat spoiling, beetles and rats appearing from nothing, and men dropping dead of strange diseases.

"jɛs," eɪvinhə sɛɾ ɪn ɹɪspɑns tə ðə mænz kwɛstʃən, "ɪt hæpənz ɔfən. mɔɹ ɔfən ɝaʊn ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ðən ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz, ət list. juv hæd sɪməlɝ ɪvɛns əmʌŋ jəɹ oʊn mɛn?"

"Yes," Aviendha said in response to the man's question, "it happens often. More often around the Car'a'carn than in other places, at least. You have had similar events among your own men?"

"aɪ hæv hɝd stɔɹiz," hi sɛd. "oʊnli aɪ dɪsmɪs ðɛm."

"I have heard stories," he said. "Only I dismissed them."

"nɑɾ ɔl stɔɹiz ɑɹ ɪɡzædʒɝeɪʃənz," ʃi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə blækən ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə soʊlʒɝ.

"Not all stories are exaggerations," she said, looking at the blackened remains of the soldier.

"ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən ɪz wik."

"The Dark One's prison is weak."

"blʌɾi æʃəz," ðə jʌŋ mæn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. "wʌɾ əv jə ɡɑɾən əs ɪntu, ɹoʊɾəl?" ðə mæn ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən stɔkt ɔf.

"Bloody ashes," the young man said, turning away. "What have you gotten us into, Rodel?" The man shook his head and stalked off.

bæʃɪɹz ɔfəsɝz bɪɡæn kɔlɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz, ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ ðə mɛn tə klin ʌp. wəd ɹænd muv aʊɾ ə ðə mænɝ, naʊ? wən pɑkəts ʌv ivəl əpɪɹd, pipəl ɔfən wɑntəd tə liv. ən jɛt, θɹu hɝ bɑnd wɪð ɹænd, ʃi fɛl noʊ ɝdʒənsi. ɪn fækt . . . ɪt sim ðəɾ i hæd ɡɔn bæk tə ɹɛst! ðət mænz mudz wɝ bɪkʌmɪŋ əz ɪɹæɾɪk əz ɪleɪnz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ pɹɛɡnənsi.

Bashere's officers began calling orders, organizing the men to clean up. Would Rand move out of the manor, now? When pockets of evil appeared, people often wanted to leave. And yet, through her bond with Rand, she felt no urgency. In fact . . . it seemed that he had gone back to rest! That man's moods were becoming as erratic as Elayne's during her pregnancy.

eɪvinhə ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən stɑɹɾəd ɡæðɝɪŋ bɝn tʃʌŋks ʌv wʊd tə hɛlp klin. əz ʃi wɝkt, sɛvɹəl ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ ən bɪɡæn ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə dæmədʒ. ði ɪntaɪɝ fɹʌn ə ðə mænɝ wɑz skɔɹd wɪð blæk mɑɹks, ən ðə hoʊl wɛɹ ði ɛntʃɹɪweɪ hæd bɪn wɑz ət lis fɪftin fiɾ əkɹɔs. wʌn ə ðə wɪmən, mɛɹaɪs, aɪɾ eɪvinhə əpɹiʃieɪɾɪvli. "ə ʃeɪm," ʃi sɛd.

Aviendha shook her head and started gathering burned chunks of wood to help clean. As she worked, several Aes Sedai came out of the building and began inspecting the damage. The entire front of the manor was scored with black marks, and the hole where the entryway had been was at least fifteen feet across. One of the women, Merise, eyed Aviendha appreciatively. "A shame," she said.

eɪvinhə stʃɹeɪɾənd ʌp, lɪftɪŋ ə pis ə tʃɑɹd wʊd, hɝ kloʊðɪŋ stɪl soʊkt. wɪð ðoʊz klaʊdz kʌvɝɪŋ ðə sʌn, ɪt wəd bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz dʒɹaɪ. "ə ʃeɪm?" ʃi æskt. "əbaʊt ðə mænɝ?" ðə pɔɹtli lɔɹd tɛleɪən, oʊnɝ ə ðə pleɪs, moʊn tə hɪmsɛlf əz i sæɾ ɑn ə stul ɪnsaɪd ði ɛntʃɹɪweɪ, waɪpɪŋ ɪz bɹaʊ ən ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd.

Aviendha straightened up, lifting a piece of charred wood, her clothing still soaked. With those clouds covering the sun, it would be long before she was dry. "A shame?" she asked. "About the manor?" The portly Lord Tellaen, owner of the place, moaned to himself as he sat on a stool inside the entryway, wiping his brow and shaking his head.

"noʊ," mɛɹaɪs sɛd. "ə ʃeɪm əbaʊt ju, tʃaɪld. jəɹ skɪl wɪð wivz, ɪts ɪmpɹɛsɪv. ɪf wi hæd jə ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, juɾ əv bɪn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ baɪ naʊ. jəɹ wivɪŋ, ɪts səm ɹʌnəs tə ɪt, bʌt jud lɝn tə fɪks ðət kwɪkli ɪf tɔt baɪ sɪstɝz."

"No," Merise said. "A shame about you, child. Your skill with weaves, it is impressive. If we had you in the White Tower, you'd have been an Aes Sedai by now. Your weaving, it has some roughness to it, but you'd learn to fix that quickly if taught by sisters."

ðəɹ wɑz ən ɑɾəbəl snɪf, ən eɪvinhə spʌn. məleɪn stʊd bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd waɪz wʌn hæɾ əɹ ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, ən əɹ stʌmək wɑz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə bʌlʒ wɪð tʃaɪld.

There was an audible sniff, and Aviendha spun. Melaine stood behind her. The golden-haired Wise One had her arms folded beneath her breasts, and her stomach was starting to bulge with child.

hɝ feɪs wɑz nɑɾ əmjuzd. haʊ hæɾ eɪvinhə lɛt ðə wʊmən wɔk ʌp bɪhaɪn əɹ wɪθaʊt hɪɹɪŋ? ʃi wɑz lɛɾɪŋ əɹ fətiɡ meɪk əɹ kɛɹləs.

Her face was not amused. How had Aviendha let the woman walk up behind her without hearing? She was letting her fatigue make her careless.

məleɪn ən mɛɹaɪs stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt; ðən ðə tɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ spʌn ɪn ə flɝi ʌv ɡɹin skɝts ən muvd ɔf tə spik wɪð ðə sɝvəns u hæd bɪn tʃɹæp baɪ ðə fleɪmz, æskɪŋ ɪf ɛni ʌv əm niɾəd hilɪŋ. məleɪn wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɪnsʌfɝəbəl wʊmən," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "tə θɪŋk, haʊ wi wʌns ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðɛm!"

Melaine and Merise stared at each other for a long moment; then the tall Aes Sedai spun in a flurry of green skirts and moved off to speak with the servants who had been trapped by the flames, asking if any of them needed Healing. Melaine watched her go, then shook her head. "Insufferable woman," she muttered. "To think, how we once regarded them!"

"waɪz wʌn?" eɪvinhə æskt.

"Wise One?" Aviendha asked.

"aɪm stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ, eɪvinhə, ən jəɹ fɑɹ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən aɪ æm. juv ə kəntʃɹoʊl ən ʌndɝstændɪŋ ʌv wivz ðət pʊts moʊst ʌv əs tə ʃeɪm. ʌðɝz əv tə stʃɹʌɡəl tə lɝn wʌt kʌmz nætʃɹəli tə ju. 'ɹʌnəs tə jəɹ wivz,' ʃi sɛz! aɪ daʊɾ ɛni ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, seɪv pɝhæps kædzueɪn sədaɪ, cʊɾə mænədʒd wʌt jə dɪd wɪð ðət kɑləm ʌv wɔɾɝ. muvɪŋ wɔɾɝ ðət fɑɹ ɹikwaɪɝd jə tə juz ðə ɹɪvɝz oʊn floʊ ən pɹɛʃɝ."

"I'm stronger than most Aes Sedai, Aviendha, and you're far stronger than I am. You have a control and understanding of weaves that puts most of us to shame. Others have to struggle to learn what comes naturally to you. 'Roughness to your weaves,' she says! I doubt any of the Aes Sedai, save perhaps Cadsuane Sedai, could have managed what you did with that column of water. Moving water that far required you to use the river's own flow and pressure."

"ɪz ðət wʌɾ aɪ dɪd?" eɪvinhə æskt, blɪŋkɪŋ.

"Is that what I did?" Aviendha asked, blinking.

məleɪn aɪd hɝ, ðən snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn, sɔfli tə hɝsɛlf. "jɛs, ðəɾ ɪz wʌt jə dɪd. juv sətʃ ɡɹeɪt tælənt, tʃaɪld."

Melaine eyed her, then snorted again, softly to herself. "Yes, that is what you did. You have such great talent, child."

eɪvinhə swɛld wɪð ðə pɹeɪz; fɹəm waɪz wʌnz, ɪt wɑz ɹɛɹ, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz sənsɪɹ.

Aviendha swelled with the praise; from Wise Ones, it was rare, but always sincere.

"bʌt jə ɹəfjuz tə lɝn," məleɪn kəntɪnjud. "ðɛɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ taɪm! hɪɹ, aɪ hæv ənʌðɝ kwɛstʃən fəɹ ju. wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə ɹænd ælθɹz plæn tə kɪdnæp ðiz dəmɑni mɝtʃən tʃifs?"

"But you refuse to learn," Melaine continued. "There isn't much time! Here, I have another question for you. What do you think of Rand al'Thor's plan to kidnap these Domani merchant chiefs?"

eɪvinhə blɪŋkt əɡɛn, soʊ taɪɝɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə θɪŋk. ɪt dɪfaɪd ɹizən ðət ðə dəmɑni juz mɝtʃəns əz liɾɝz ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. haʊ kəɾ ə mɝtʃən lɛd pipəl? dɪd nɑt mɝtʃəns əv tə foʊkəs ɑn ðɛɹ wɛɹz? ɪt wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs. wəd ðə wɛtləndɝz ɛvɝ stɑp ʃɑkɪŋ əɹ wɪð ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ weɪz?

Aviendha blinked again, so tired it was hard to think. It defied reason that the Domani used merchants as leaders in the first place. How could a merchant lead people? Did not merchants have to focus on their wares? It was ridiculous. Would the wetlanders ever stop shocking her with their strange ways?

ən waɪ wɑz məleɪn æskɪŋ əɹ əbaʊt ðɪs naʊ ʌv ɔl taɪmz?

And why was Melaine asking her about this now of all times?

"hɪz plæn simz ə ɡʊd wʌn, waɪz wʌn," eɪvinhə sɛd. "jɛt ðə spɪɹz də nɑt laɪk biɪŋ juz fəɹ kɪdnæpɪŋ. aɪ θɪŋk ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ʃʊɾə spoʊkən ɪn tɝmz ʌv ɔfɝɪŋ pɹətɛkʃən - fɔɹs pɹətɛkʃən - fəɹ ðə mɝtʃəns. ðə tʃifs wʊɾə ɹɪspɑndɪd bɛɾɝ tə biɪŋ toʊl ðeɪ wɝ pɹətɛktɪŋ ɹæðɝ ðən kɪdnæpɪŋ."

"His plan seems a good one, Wise One," Aviendha said. "Yet the spears do not like being used for kidnapping. I think the Car'a'carn should have spoken in terms of offering protection - forced protection - for the merchants. The chiefs would have responded better to being told they were protecting rather than kidnapping."

"ðeɪ wəd bi duɪŋ ðə vɛɹi seɪm θɪŋ, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt jə kɔl ɪt."

"They would be doing the very same thing, no matter what you call it."

"bʌt wʌt jə kɔl ə θɪŋ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt," eɪvinhə sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt dɪsɑnəst ɪf boʊθ dɛfənɪʃənz ɑɹ tʃɹu."

"But what you call a thing is important," Aviendha said. "It is not dishonest if both definitions are true."

məleɪnz aɪz twɪŋkəld, ən eɪvinhə kɑɾ ə hɪn ʌv ə smaɪl ɑn əɹ lɪps. "wʌɾ ɛls dʒju θɪŋk ə ðə miɾɪŋ?"

Melaine's eyes twinkled, and Aviendha caught a hint of a smile on her lips. "What else do you think of the meeting?"

"ɹæn ælθɹ stɪl simz tə θɪŋk ðət ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn kən meɪk dɪmænz laɪk ə wɛtləndɝ kɪŋ.

"Rand al'Thor still seems to think that the Car'a'carn can make demands like a wetlander king.

ðɪs ɪz maɪ ʃeɪm. aɪ feɪl tə ɪkspleɪn ðə ɹaɪt weɪ."

This is my shame. I failed to explain the right way."

məleɪn weɪvd ə hænd. "ju hæv noʊ ʃeɪm ðɛɹ. wi ɔl noʊ haʊ bʊlhɛɾɪd ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɪz. ðə waɪz wʌnz əv tʃɹaɪɾ əz wɛl, ən nʌn əv bɪn eɪbəl tə tʃɹeɪn ɪm kɝɛkli."

Melaine waved a hand. "You have no shame there. We all know how bullheaded the Car'a'carn is. The Wise Ones have tried as well, and none have been able to train him correctly."

soʊ. ðət wɑzn ðə ɹizən fəɹ əɹ dɪsɑnɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz. wʌt wɑz ɪt ðɛn? eɪvinhə ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, ðən fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə kəntɪnju. "ɹəɡɑɹdləs, hi nidz tə bi ɹimaɪndəd.

So. That wasn't the reason for her dishonor before the Wise Ones. What was it then? Aviendha ground her teeth in frustration, then forced herself to continue. "Regardless, he needs to be reminded.

əɡɛn ən əɡɛn. ɹəɑɹk ɪz ə waɪz ən peɪʃən mæn, bʌt nɑɾ ɔl klæn tʃifs ɑɹ soʊ. aɪ noʊ ðət səm ə ði ʌðɝz wʌndɝ ɪf ðɛɹ dɪsɪʒən tə fɑloʊ ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz ən ɛɹɝ."

Again and again. Rhuarc is a wise and patient man, but not all clan chiefs are so. I know that some of the others wonder if their decision to follow Rand al'Thor was an error."

"tʃɹu," məleɪn sɛd. "bʌt lʊk ət wʌt hæpən tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ."

"True," Melaine said. "But look at what happened to the Shaido."

"aɪ dɪd nɑt seɪ ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt, waɪz wʌn," eɪvinhə sɛd. ə ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz wɝ hɛzɪɾəntli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹaɪ ʌp ðə ɡlæsi blæk maʊnd. ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə hæv fjuz tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. eɪvinhə loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɔŋ tə kwɛstʃən ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ spikɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɹænd ælθɹ nidz tə ɹilaɪz ðət ðəl nɑɾ æksɛpt əfɛns æftɝ əfɛns fɹəm ɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɛnd. ðeɪ meɪ nɑt tɝn əɡɛnst ɪm laɪk ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, bʌɾ aɪ wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæs tɪmoʊlən - fəɹ ɪnstəns - tə sɪmpli ɹɪtɝn tə ðə θɹi-foʊld læn ən liv ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn tə hɪz ɛɹəɡəns."

"I did not say they were right, Wise One," Aviendha said. A group of soldiers were hesitantly trying to pry up the glassy black mound. It appeared to have fused to the ground. Aviendha lowered her voice. "They are wrong to question the Car'a'carn, but they are speaking to one another. Rand al'Thor needs to realize that they will not accept offense after offense from him without end. They may not turn against him like the Shaido, but I would not put it past Timolan - for instance - to simply return to the Three-fold Land and leave the Car'a'carn to his arrogance."

məleɪn nɑɾəd. "du nɑt wɝi. wəɹ əwɛɹ ə ðɪs . . . pɑsəbɪləɾi."

Melaine nodded. "Do not worry. We are aware of this . . . possibility."

ðət mɛnt waɪz wʌnz hæd bɪn sɛn tə suð tɪmoʊlən, hu wɑz tʃif ə ðə maɪæɡoʊmə il. ɪt wəd nɑt bi ðə fɝs taɪm. dɪd ɹænd ælθɹ noʊ haʊ hɑɹd ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝk bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk tə meɪnteɪn il lɔɪəlti? pɹɑbli nɑt. hi sɔ ðɛm ɔl əz wʌn hoʊmədʒiniəs ɡɹup, swɔɹn tə hɪm, tə bi juzd. ðət wɑz wʌn ə ɹændz ɡɹeɪt wiknəsəz. hi kəd nɑt si ðəɾ il, laɪk ʌðɝ pipəl, dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ juzd əz tulz. ðə klænz wɝ fɑɹ lɛs taɪtli nɪt ðən i bɪlivd. blʌd fjudz hæd bɪn pʊɾ əsaɪd fəɹ hɪm. kʊdn i ʌndɝstæn haʊ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ðət wɑz? kʊdn i si haʊ tɛnjəwəs ðəɾ əlaɪəns kəntɪnjud tə bi?

That meant Wise Ones had been sent to soothe Timolan, who was chief of the Miagoma Aiel. It would not be the first time. Did Rand al'Thor know how hard the Wise Ones worked behind his back to maintain Aiel loyalty? Probably not. He saw them all as one homogeneous group, sworn to him, to be used. That was one of Rand's great weaknesses. He could not see that Aiel, like other people, did not like being used as tools. The clans were far less tightly knit than he believed. Blood feuds had been put aside for him. Couldn't he understand how incredible that was? Couldn't he see how tenuous that alliance continued to be?

bʌt nɑɾ oʊnli wɑz i ə wɛtləndɝ baɪ bɝθ, hi wɑz nɑɾ ə waɪz wʌn. fju il ðɛmsɛlvz sɔ ðə wɝk ðə waɪz wʌnz dɪɾ ɪn ə dʌzən dɪfɹən ɛɹiəz. haʊ sɪmpəl laɪf hæd simd wən ʃi hæd bɪn ə meɪɾən! ɪt wʊɾə dæzəld əɹ tə noʊ haʊ mʌtʃ wɛn ɑn bɪɑn əɹ saɪt.

But not only was he a wetlander by birth, he was not a Wise One. Few Aiel themselves saw the work the Wise Ones did in a dozen different areas. How simple life had seemed when she had been a Maiden! It would have dazzled her to know how much went on beyond her sight.

məleɪn stɛɹd blaɪnli ət ðə bɹoʊkən bɪldɪŋ. "ə ɹɛmnən ʌv ə ɹɛmnənt," ʃi sɛd, əz ɪf tə hɝsɛlf.

Melaine stared blindly at the broken building. "A remnant of a remnant," she said, as if to herself.

"æn ɪf i livz əs bɝn ən bɹoʊkən, laɪk ðoʊz bɔɹdz? wʌt wɪl bɪkʌm ə ði il ðɛn? də wi lɪmp bæk tə ðə θɹi-foʊld læn ən kəntɪnju əz wi dɪd bɪfɔɹ? mɛni wɪl nɑt wɑnə liv.

"And if he leaves us burned and broken, like those boards? What will become of the Aiel then? Do we limp back to the Three-fold Land and continue as we did before? Many will not want to leave.

ðiz lænz ɔfɝ tu mʌtʃ."

These lands offer too much."

eɪvinhə blɪŋkt ət ðə weɪɾ ə ðoʊz wɝdz. ʃi hæd ɹɛɹli ɡɪvən θɔt tə wʌt wəd hæpən æftɝ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn wɑz fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðɛm. ʃi wɑz sɛntɝɾ ɑn ðə naʊ, əpɑn ɹɪɡeɪnɪŋ əɹ ɑnɝ ən biɪŋ ðəɹ tə pɹətɛkt ɹænd ælθɹ ət ðə læs bæɾəl. bʌɾ ə waɪz wʌn kəd nɑt dʒʌs θɪŋk ə ðə naʊ əɹ ðə təmɑɹoʊ. ʃi hæd tə θɪŋk ə ðə jɪɹz əhɛɾ ən ðə taɪmz ðət wəd bi bɹɔɾ əpɑn ðə wɪnz.

Aviendha blinked at the weight of those words. She had rarely given thought to what would happen after the Car'a'carn was finished with them. She was centered on the now, upon regaining her honor and being there to protect Rand al'Thor at the Last Battle. But a Wise One could not just think of the now or the tomorrow. She had to think of the years ahead and the times that would be brought upon the winds.

ə ɹɛmnən ʌv ə ɹɛmnənt. hi hæd bɹoʊkən ði il əz ə pipəl. wʌt wəd bɪkʌm ə ðɛm?

A remnant of a remnant. He had broken the Aiel as a people. What would become of them?

məleɪn ɡlæns bæk əɾ eɪvinhə, hɝ feɪs sɔfənɪŋ. "ɡoʊ tə ðə tɛns, tʃaɪld, ən ɹɛst. jə lʊk laɪk ə ʃɝəɾən ðəɾ əz kɹɔld ɑn ɪz bɛli əkɹɔs θɹi deɪz ə sænd."

Melaine glanced back at Aviendha, her face softening. "Go to the tents, child, and rest. You look like a sharadan that has crawled on his belly across three days of sand."

eɪvinhə lʊk daʊn əɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, siɪŋ ðə fleɪks ʌv æʃ fɹəm ðə bɝnɪŋz. hɝ kloʊðɪŋ wɑz soʊkt ən steɪnd, ən ʃi səspɛktəd ðəɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz dʒʌst əz fɪlθi. hɝ ɑɹmz ætʃt fɹəm kæɹiɪŋ ðə stoʊnz ɔl deɪ. wʌns ʃi æknɑlɪdʒ ðə fətiɡ, ɪt sim tə kɹæʃ əpɑn əɹ laɪk ə wɪndstɔɹm.

Aviendha looked down at her arms, seeing the flakes of ash from the burnings. Her clothing was soaked and stained, and she suspected that her face was just as filthy. Her arms ached from carrying the stones all day. Once she acknowledged the fatigue, it seemed to crash upon her like a windstorm.

ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ ən fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə ɹɪmeɪn əpɹaɪt. ʃi wəd nɑt ʃeɪm hɝsɛlf baɪ kəlæpsɪŋ!

She gritted her teeth and forced herself to remain upright. She would not shame herself by collapsing!

bʌt ʃi dɪd tɝn tə liv, əz ɪnstʃɹʌktəd.

But she did turn to leave, as instructed.

"oʊ, ən eɪvinhə," məleɪn kɔld. "wi wɪl dɪskʌs jəɹ pʌnɪʃmən təmɑɹoʊ."

"Oh, and Aviendha," Melaine called. "We will discuss your punishment tomorrow."

ʃi tɝn ɪn ʃɑk.

She turned in shock.

"fɔɹ nɑt fɪnɪʃɪŋ wɪð ðə stoʊnz," məleɪn sɛd, sɝveɪɪŋ ðə ɹɛkədʒ əɡɛn. "æn fəɹ nɑt lɝnɪŋ kwɪkli ɪnʌf. ɡoʊ."

"For not finishing with the stones," Melaine said, surveying the wreckage again. "And for not learning quickly enough. Go."

eɪvinhə saɪd. ənʌðɝ ɹaʊn ə kwɛstʃənz, ən ənʌðɝ ʌndɪzɝv pʌnɪʃmənt. ðəɹ wɑz ə kɔɹəleɪʃən ə səm sɔɹt. bʌt wʌt?

Aviendha sighed. Another round of questions, and another undeserved punishment. There was a correlation of some sort. But what?

ʃi wɑz tu ɪɡzɔstəd tə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt fəɹ naʊ. ɔl ʃi wɑntəd wɑz əɹ bɛd, ən ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf tʃɹɛtʃɝəsli ɹɪkɔlɪŋ ðə sɑft, ləɡʒɝiəs mætʃɹəsəz bæk ɪn ðə pæləs ə keɪɛmlɪn. ʃi fɔɹs ðoʊz θɔts aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪnd. slip ðət saʊnli, mʌfəld ɪn pɪloʊz ən daʊn kʌmfɝɾɝz, ən jud bi tu ɹɪlæks tə weɪk ɪf sʌmwʌn tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl jə ɪn ðə naɪt! haʊ hæd ʃi lɛɾ ɪleɪn kənvɪns əɹ tə slip ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz sɑft-fɛðɝd dɛθ tʃɹæps?

She was too exhausted to think about it for now. All she wanted was her bed, and she found herself treacherously recalling the soft, luxurious mattresses back in the palace of Caemlyn. She forced those thoughts out of her mind. Sleep that soundly, muffled in pillows and down comforters, and you'd be too relaxed to wake if someone tried to kill you in the night! How had she let Elayne convince her to sleep in one of those soft-feathered death traps?

ənʌðɝ θɔɾ əkɝd tə hɝ əz ʃi pʊʃt ðət wʌn əweɪ - ə tʃɹɛtʃɝəs wʌn. ə θɔɾ ə ɹænd ælθɹ, ɹɛstɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɹum. ʃi kəd ɡoʊ tə hɪm. . . .

Another thought occurred to her as she pushed that one away - a treacherous one. A thought of Rand al'Thor, resting in his room. She could go to him. . . .

noʊ! nɑɾ əntɪl ʃi hæɾ əɹ ɑnɝ bæk. ʃi wəd nɑt ɡoʊ tə hɪm əz ə bɛɡɝ. ʃi wəd ɡoʊ tə hɪm əz ə wʊmən ʌv ɑnɝ. əsumɪŋ ðət ʃi kəɾ ɛvɝ fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ɹɔŋ.

No! Not until she had her honor back. She would not go to him as a beggar. She would go to him as a woman of honor. Assuming that she could ever figure out what she was doing wrong.

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən tʃɹɑɾəd təwɔɹd ði il kæmp ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹin.

She shook her head and trotted toward the Aiel camp at the side of the green.

tʃæptɝ twɛlv

CHAPTER 12

ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ ɪnkaʊntɝz ɛɡwin wɔk ðə kævɝnəs hɔlz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, lɔst ɪn θɔt. hɝ tu ɹɛd kipɝz tʃɹeɪld əlɔŋ bɪhaɪnd. ðeɪ simd ə lɪɾəl sʌlən ðiz deɪz. ɪleɪɾə ɔɹɾɝd əm tə steɪ wɪð ɛɡwin mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ɔfən; ðoʊ ði ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz tʃeɪnʒd, ðəɹ wɝ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz tu wɪð hɝ. ən jɛt, ɪt sim ðət ðeɪ kəd sɛns ðəɾ ɛɡwin kənsɪɾɝd əm tə bi ətɛndəns ɹæðɝ ðən ɡɑɹdz.

Unexpected Encounters Egwene walked the cavernous halls of the White Tower, lost in thought. Her two Red keepers trailed along behind. They seemed a little sullen these days. Elaida ordered them to stay with Egwene more and more often; though the individuals changed, there were almost always two with her. And yet, it seemed that they could sense that Egwene considered them to be attendants rather than guards.

ɪt hæd bɪn wɛl oʊvɝ ə mʌnθ sɪns sɪuən hæd kənveɪɾ əɹ dɪstɝbɪŋ nuz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, bʌt stɪl ɛɡwin θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt. ði ɪvɛns wɝ ə ɹimaɪndɝ ðət ðə wɝld wɑz kʌmɪŋ əpɑɹt. ðɪs wɑz ə taɪm wən ðə waɪt taʊɝ ʃʊɾə bɪn ə sɔɹs ə stəbɪlɪɾi. ɪnstɛd, ɪt dɪvaɪɾəd əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf waɪl ɹænd ælθɹz mɛn bɑndəd sɪstɝz. haʊ kəd ɹænd əv əlaʊd sətʃ ə θɪŋ? ðəɹ wɑz ɑbviəsli lɪɾəl lɛft ə ðə juθ wɪð hum ʃid ɡɹoʊn ʌp. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl ə ðə juθfəl ɛɡwin lɛft iðɝ. ɡɔn wɝ ðə deɪz wən ðə tu ʌv əm hæd sim dɛstɪn tə ɛn ʌp mɛɹid, lɪvɪŋ ɑn ə lɪɾəl fɑɹm ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

It had been well over a month since Siuan had conveyed her disturbing news in Tel'aran'rhiod, but still Egwene thought about it. The events were a reminder that the world was coming apart. This was a time when the White Tower should have been a source of stability. Instead, it divided against itself while Rand al'Thor's men bonded sisters. How could Rand have allowed such a thing? There was obviously little left of the youth with whom she'd grown up. Of course, there was little of the youthful Egwene left either. Gone were the days when the two of them had seemed destined to end up married, living on a little farm in the Two Rivers.

ðæt, ɑdli, lɛɾ əɹ tə θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɡɔɪn. haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ ɪt bɪn sɪns ʃid læst sin hɪm, stilɪŋ kɪsəz ɪn kɛɹhin? wɛɹ wɑz i naʊ? wɑz i seɪf?

That, oddly, led her to thinking of Gawyn. How long had it been since she'd last seen him, stealing kisses in Cairhien? Where was he now? Was he safe?

kip foʊkəst, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf. klin ðə pætʃ ə flɔɹ jəɹ wɝkɪŋ ɑn fɝs bɪfɔɹ jə muv ɑn tə ðə ɹɛst ə ðə haʊs. ɡɔɪn kəd lʊk æftɝ hɪmsɛlf; hid dʌn ə kɑmpəɾənt dʒɑb ə ðəɾ ɪn ðə pæst. tu kɑmpəɾənt, ɪn səm keɪsəz.

Keep focused, she told herself. Clean the patch of floor you're working on first before you move on to the rest of the house. Gawyn could look after himself; he'd done a competent job of that in the past. Too competent, in some cases.

sɪuən ən ði ʌðɝz wəd dil wɪð ði æʃəmən mæɾɝ. ði ʌðɝ nuz wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ dɪstɝbɪŋ. wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ɪn ðə kæmp? ə wʊmən, jɛt tʃænəlɪŋ seɪɾɪn ɪnstɛɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ?

Siuan and the others would deal with the Asha'man matter. The other news was far more disturbing. One of the Forsaken, in the camp? A woman, yet channeling saidin instead of saidar?

ɛɡwin wʊɾə kɔld ɪɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl, wʌns. jɛt ʃi hæd sin ɡoʊsts ɪn ðə hɔlz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz sim tə ɹiɝeɪnʒ ɑn ə deɪli beɪsəs. ðɪs wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ saɪn.

Egwene would have called it impossible, once. Yet she had seen ghosts in the halls of the White Tower, and the corridors seemed to rearrange on a daily basis. This was just another sign.

ʃi ʃɪvɝd. hɑlimə hæd tʌtʃt ɛɡwin, səpoʊzədli məsɑʒɪŋ əɹ hɛdeɪks əweɪ. ðoʊz hɛdeɪks dɪsəpɪɹɾ əz sun əz ɛɡwin hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd; waɪ hædnt ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ðət hɑlimə maɪɾ əv bɪn kɑzɪŋ ðɛm? wʌɾ ɛls hæd ðə wʊmən bɪn plɑɾɪŋ? wʌt hɪɾən nɑts wəd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stʌmbəl oʊvɝ, wʌt tʃɹæps hæd ʃi leɪd?

She shivered. Halima had touched Egwene, supposedly massaging her headaches away. Those headaches disappeared as soon as Egwene had been captured; why hadn't she considered that Halima might have been causing them? What else had the woman been plotting? What hidden knots would the Aes Sedai stumble over, what traps had she laid?

wʌn sɛkʃən ə ðə flɔɹ əɾ ə taɪm. klin wʌt jə kəd ɹitʃ, ðən muv ɑn. sɪuən ən ði ʌðɝz wəɾ əv tə dil wɪð hɑliməz plɑts, tu.

One section of the floor at a time. Clean what you could reach, then move on. Siuan and the others would have to deal with Halima's plots, too.

ɛɡwinz bæksaɪd hɝt, bʌt ðə peɪn wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɪɹɛləvən tə hɝ. səmtaɪmz ʃi læft wən biɾən, səmtaɪmz nɑt. ðə stʃɹæp wɑz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ peɪn - wʌt hæd bɪn dʌn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn - wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ dɪmændɪŋ. ʃi nɑɾəd tə ə ɡɹup ʌv waɪt-kloʊð nɑvəsɪz əz ðeɪ pæst əɹ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ, ən ðeɪ bɑb daʊn ɪn kɝtsiz. ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd, bʌt dɪdn tʃæstaɪz əm - ʃi dʒʌs hoʊp ðət ðeɪ wʊdn dʒɹɔ pɛnənsɪz fɹəm ðə tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ɹɛdz fəɹ ʃoʊɪŋ dɛfɝəns tə ɛɡwin.

Egwene's backside hurt, but the pain was growing increasingly irrelevant to her. Sometimes she laughed when beaten, sometimes not. The strap was unimportant. The greater pain - what had been done to Tar Valon - was far more demanding. She nodded to a group of white-clothed novices as they passed her in the hallway, and they bobbed down in curtsies. Egwene frowned, but didn't chastise them - she just hoped that they wouldn't draw penances from the trailing Reds for showing deference to Egwene.

hɝ ɡoʊl wɑz ðə kɔɹɾɝz ə ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, ðə sɛkʃən ðət wɑz naʊ daʊn ɪn ðə wɪŋ.

Her goal was the quarters of the Brown Ajah, the section that was now down in the wing.

maɪdɑni hæd teɪkən əɹ taɪm vɔləntɪɹɪŋ tə tʃɹeɪn ɛɡwin tədeɪ. ðə kəmæn hæd faɪnəli kʌm tədeɪ, wiks æftɝ ðə fɝs dɪnɝ wɪð ɪleɪɾə. ɑdli, haʊɛvɝ, bɛn nælsəd hæɾ ɔlsoʊ ɔfɝd tə ɡɪv əɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən ðɪs deɪ. ɛɡwin hædn spoʊkən tə ðə ʃaɪnɝən bɹaʊn sɪns ðət fɝs kɑnvɝseɪʃən, səm wiks bɪfɔɹ. ʃid nɛvɝ ɹɪpiɾɪd lɛsənz wɪð ðə seɪm wʊmən twaɪs. ən jɛt, ðə neɪm hæd bɪn ɡɪvən tə hɝ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ əz ðə fɝst ə ðə deɪz vɪzəts.

Meidani had taken her time volunteering to train Egwene today. The command had finally come today, weeks after the first dinner with Elaida. Oddly, however, Bennae Nalsad had also offered to give her instruction this day. Egwene hadn't spoken to the Shienaran Brown since that first conversation, some weeks before. She'd never repeated lessons with the same woman twice. And yet, the name had been given to her in the morning as the first of the day's visits.

wən ʃi ɹitʃt ði ist wɪŋ, wɪtʃ naʊ hɛl ðə bɹaʊn sɛktɝ ə ðə taʊɝ, hɝ ɹɛd maɪndɝz ɹɪlʌktənli tʊk ʌp pəzɪʃənz ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ ɹɪtɝn. ɪleɪɾə pɹɑbli wʊɾə laɪkt əm tə steɪ wɪð ɛɡwin, bʌɾ æftɝ ðə ɹɛdz ðɛmsɛlvz hæd bɪn soʊ ɪɡzæktɪŋ ɪn pɹətɛktɪŋ ðɛɹ baʊndɝi, ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl tʃæns ʌv ənʌðɝ ədʒɑ - ivən ðə maɪl bɹaʊnz - lɛɾɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə ɹɛd sɪstɝz ɪnfɪltʃɹeɪt ðɛɹ kɔɹɾɝz. ɛɡwin hɝiɾ əɹ peɪs əz ʃi ɛntɝd ðə sɛkʃən wɪð bɹaʊn taɪl flɔɹz, pæsɪŋ bʌsəlɪŋ wɪmən ɪn nɑndɪskɹɪpt, mjuɾɪd dʒɹɛsəz. ɪt wɑz gɑnə bi ə fʊl deɪ, wɪð əɹ əpɔɪnmənts wɪð sɪstɝz, hɝ skɛdʒʊl biɾɪŋz, ən əɹ ɹɛɡjəlɝ nɑvəs loʊɾ ə skɹʌbɪŋ flɔɹz əɹ ʌðɝ tʃɔɹz.

When she reached the east wing, which now held the Brown sector of the Tower, her Red minders reluctantly took up positions in the hallway outside, waiting for her return. Elaida probably would have liked them to stay with Egwene, but after the Reds themselves had been so exacting in protecting their boundary, there was little chance of another Ajah - even the mild Browns - letting a pair of Red sisters infiltrate their quarters. Egwene hurried her pace as she entered the section with brown tiled floors, passing bustling women in nondescript, muted dresses. It was going to be a full day, with her appointments with sisters, her scheduled beatings, and her regular novice load of scrubbing floors or other chores.

ʃi ɝaɪvd ət bɛnz dɔɹ, bʌt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ðɛɹ. moʊst sɪstɝz əɡɹid tə tʃɹeɪn ɛɡwin oʊnli wən fɔɹst ɪndə ðə duɾi, ən ði ɪkspɪɹiəns wɑz ɔfən ənplɛzənt. səm ʌv ɛɡwinz titʃɝz dɪslaɪkt əɹ kəz ə hɝ əfɪlieɪʃən wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz, ʌðɝz wɝ ənɔɪd baɪ haʊ izəli ʃi kəd kɹæft wivz, ən stɪl ʌðɝz wɝ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾəd tə faɪn ðət ʃi wəd nɑt ʃoʊ ðɛm ɹɪspɛk laɪk ə nɑvəs.

She arrived at Bennae's door, but hesitated there. Most sisters agreed to train Egwene only when forced into the duty, and the experience was often unpleasant. Some of Egwene's teachers disliked her because of her affiliation with the rebels, others were annoyed by how easily she could craft weaves, and still others were infuriated to find that she would not show them respect like a novice.

ðiz "lɛsənz," haʊɛvɝ, hæd bɪn əmʌŋ ɛɡwinz bɛs tʃænsəz tə saʊ sidz əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə.

These "lessons," however, had been among Egwene's best chances to sow seeds against Elaida.

ʃid plæntəd wʌn ə ðoʊz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ fɝs vɪzət wɪð bɛn. hæɾ ɪt bɪɡʌn tə spɹaʊt?

She'd planted one of those during her first visit with Bennae. Had it begun to sprout?

ɛɡwin nɑkt, ən ðən ɛntɝɾ ət ðə kɔl tə kʌm ɪn. ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ɪnsaɪd wɑz klʌɾɝd wɪð ðə ɹɛfjus ə skɑlɝʃɪp. stæks ən stæks ə bʊks - laɪk mɪniətʃʊɹ sɪɾi taʊɝz - lin əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ. skɛləɾənz ə vɛɹiəs kɹitʃɝz wɝ maʊntəɾ ɪn vɛɹiəs steɪts ə kənstʃɹʌkʃən; ðə wʊmən oʊn ɪnʌf boʊnz tə pɑpjəleɪɾ ə mənædʒɝi. ɛɡwin ʃɪvɝd wən ʃi noʊɾəst ə fʊl hjumən skɛləɾən ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, hɛld əpɹaɪɾ ən baʊn təɡɛðɝ wɪð θɹɛdz, səm dɪteɪl noʊteɪʃənz ɹɪɾən dɝɛkli ɑn ðə boʊnz ɪn blæk ɪŋk.

Egwene knocked, and then entered at the call to come in. The sitting room inside was cluttered with the refuse of scholarship. Stacks and stacks of books - like miniature city towers - leaned against one another. Skeletons of various creatures were mounted in various states of construction; the woman owned enough bones to populate a menagerie. Egwene shivered when she noticed a full human skeleton in the corner, held upright and bound together with threads, some detailed notations written directly on the bones in black ink.

ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɹum tə wɔk ən oʊnli wʌn klɪɹ pleɪs tə sɪt - bɛnz oʊn stʌf tʃɛɹ, ði ɑɹmɹɛsts wɔɹn wɪð ə twɪn sɛɾ ə dɪpɹɛʃənz, daʊtləs wɛɹ ðə bɹaʊnz ɑɹmz hæd ɹɛstəd dʊɹɪŋ kaʊnləs leɪt-naɪt ɹiɾɪŋ sɛʃənz. ðə loʊ silɪŋ fɛlt loʊɝ fəɹ ðə sɛvɹəl mʌmɪfaɪd faʊl ən æstʃɹənɑmɪkəl kəntʃɹæpʃənz wɪtʃ hʌŋ əbʌv. ɛɡwin hæd tə dʌk əɹ hɛd bɪniθ ə mɑɾəl ə ðə sʌn ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹitʃ ðə pleɪs wɛɹ bɛn stʊd ɹaɪflɪŋ θɹu ə stæk ə lɛðɝ-baʊn vɑljumz.

There was barely room to walk and only one clear place to sit - Bennae's own stuffed chair, the armrests worn with a twin set of depressions, doubtless where the Brown's arms had rested during countless late-night reading sessions. The low ceiling felt lower for the several mummified fowl and astronomical contraptions which hung above. Egwene had to duck her head beneath a model of the sun in order to reach the place where Bennae stood rifling through a stack of leather-bound volumes.

"ɑ," ʃi sɛɾ əz ʃi noʊɾəst ɛɡwin. "ɡʊd." slɛndɝ ɪn ə boʊni sɔɹɾ ʌv weɪ, ʃi hæd dɑɹk hɛɹ ðət wɑz stʃɹikt wɪð ɡɹeɪ fɹəm eɪdʒ. ðə hɛɹ wɑz ɪn ə bʌn, ən ʃi - laɪk mɛni bɹaʊnz - wɔɹ ə sɪmpəl dʒɹɛs ðət hædn bɪn fæʃənəbəl fəɹ ə sɛntʃɝi əɹ tu.

"Ah," she said as she noticed Egwene. "Good." Slender in a bony sort of way, she had dark hair that was streaked with gray from age. The hair was in a bun, and she - like many Browns - wore a simple dress that hadn't been fashionable for a century or two.

bɛn muvd oʊvɝ tə hɝ stʌf sɪɾɪŋ tʃɛɹ, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə stɪfɝ tʃɛɹz baɪ ðə hɑɹθ - boʊθ ə ðoʊz hæɾ əkjumjəleɪɾəd stæks ə peɪpɝz sɪns ɛɡwinz pɹiviəs vɪzət. ɛɡwin klɪɹɾ ɔf ə stul, pleɪsɪŋ ðə dʌsti skɛləɾən ʌv ə ɹæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪtwin tu stæks ə bʊks əbaʊt ðə ɹeɪn ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ.

Bennae moved over to her stuffed sitting chair, ignoring the stiffer chairs by the hearth - both of those had accumulated stacks of papers since Egwene's previous visit. Egwene cleared off a stool, placing the dusty skeleton of a rat on the floor between two stacks of books about the reign of Artur Hawkwing.

"wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz wi ʃəd ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð jəɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən, ðɛn," bɛn sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ.

"Well, I suppose we should get on with your instruction, then," Bennae said, settling back in her chair.

ɛɡwin kɛpt əɹ feɪs kɑm. hæd bɛn ɹɪkwɛstɪɾ ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə tʃɹeɪn ɛɡwin əɡɛn? əɹ hæd ʃi bɪn fɔɹst ɪndə ɪt? ɛɡwin kəd si ən ʌnsəfɪstɪkeɪɾɪd bɹaʊn sɪstɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɪpiɾɪdli ɹoʊpt ɪndə ə duɾi ðət noʊbɑdi ɛls wɑntəd.

Egwene kept her face calm. Had Bennae requested an opportunity to train Egwene again? Or had she been forced into it? Egwene could see an unsophisticated Brown sister getting repeatedly roped into a duty that nobody else wanted.

ət bɛnz ɹɪkwɛst, ɛɡwin pɝfɔɹmd ə nʌmbɝ ʌv wivz, wɝk fɑɹ bɪɑn ðə skɪl ə moʊs nɑvəsɪz bʌɾ izi fəɹ ɛɡwin, ivən wɪð əɹ paʊɝ dæmpən baɪ fɔkɹut. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə tiz aʊt ðə bɹaʊnz filɪŋz ɑn ðə ɹiloʊkeɪʃən ə hɝ kɔɹɾɝz, bʌt bɛn - laɪk moʊst ə ðə bɹaʊnz ɛɡwin hæd spoʊkən tə - pɹəfɝd tə əvɔɪd ðət tɑpɪk.

At Bennae's request, Egwene performed a number of weaves, work far beyond the skill of most novices but easy for Egwene, even with her power dampened by forkroot. She tried to tease out the Brown's feelings on the relocation of her quarters, but Bennae - like most of the Browns Egwene had spoken to - preferred to avoid that topic.

ɛɡwin dɪd səm mɔɹ wivz. æftɝ ə taɪm, ʃi wʌndɝd dʒʌst wʌt ðə pɔɪn ə ðə miɾɪŋ wɑz. hædn bɛn æskt əɹ tə dɛmənstʃɹeɪt moʊst ə ðiz vɛɹi seɪm wivz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ pɹiviəs vɪzət?

Egwene did some more weaves. After a time, she wondered just what the point of the meeting was. Hadn't Bennae asked her to demonstrate most of these very same weaves during her previous visit?

"vɛɹi wɛl," bɛn sɛd, ɡɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti fɹəm ə pɑt wɔɹmɪŋ ɑn ə smɔl koʊl bɹeɪziɝ.

"Very well," Bennae said, getting herself a cup of tea from a pot warming on a small coal brazier.

ʃi dɪdn ɔfɝ ɛni ti tə ɛɡwin. "ju ɑɹ skɪld ɪnʌf ət ðæt. bʌɾ aɪ wʌndɝ. juv ðə ʃɑɹpnəs ə maɪnd, ði əbɪləɾi tə dil wɪð dɪfəkəl sɪtʃueɪʃənz, ðəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz ɹikwaɪɝd tə hæv?"

She didn't offer any tea to Egwene. "You are skilled enough at that. But I wonder. Do you have the sharpness of mind, the ability to deal with difficult situations, that an Aes Sedai is required to have?"

ɛɡwin sɛd nʌθɪŋ, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd pɔɪntɪdli pɔɹ hɝsɛlf səm ti. bɛn dɪd nɑɾ əbdʒɛkt.

Egwene said nothing, though she did pointedly pour herself some tea. Bennae did not object.

"lɛts si . . ." bɛn mjuzd. "səpoʊz ðət jə wɝ ɪn ə sɪtʃueɪʃən wɛɹ jə wɝ ɪn kɑnflɪkt wɪð səm mɛmbɝz ə jəɹ oʊn ədʒɑ. juv hæpən əpɑn ɪnfɝmeɪʃən jə wɝn səpoʊz tə noʊ, ən jəɹ ədʒɑz liɾɝz ɑɹ kwaɪɾ əpsɛt wɪð ju. sʌɾənli, jə faɪn jɝsɛlf biɪŋ sɛntəns tə səm moʊst ənplɛzən duɾiz, əz ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə swip jə ʌndɝ ðə ɹʌɡ ən fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ju.

"Let's see . . ." Bennae mused. "Suppose that you were in a situation where you were in conflict with some members of your own Ajah. You have happened upon information you weren't supposed to know, and your Ajah's leaders are quite upset with you. Suddenly, you find yourself being sentenced to some most unpleasant duties, as if they are trying to sweep you under the rug and forget about you.

tɛl mi, ɪn ðɪs sɪtʃueɪʃən, haʊ wəd jə ɹiækt?"

Tell me, in this situation, how would you react?"

ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊkt ɑn əɹ ti. ðə bɹaʊn wɑzn vɛɹi sʌɾəl. ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn æskɪŋ əbaʊt ðə θɝtinθ dɪpɑzətɔɹi, hæd ʃi? ən ðət hæd lændəɾ əɹ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl? fju wɝ səpoʊz tə noʊ əbaʊt ðə sikɹət hɪstɝiz ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd mɛnʃən soʊ kæʒəwəli dʊɹɪŋ əɹ pɹiviəs vɪzət hɪɹ.

Egwene almost choked on her tea. The Brown wasn't very subtle. She had begun asking about the Thirteenth Depository, had she? And that had landed her in trouble? Few were supposed to know about the secret histories that Egwene had mentioned so casually during her previous visit here.

"wɛl," ɛɡwin sɛd, sɪpɪŋ əɹ ti, "lɛt mi əpɹoʊtʃ ɪt wɪð ə klɪɹ maɪnd. bɛs tə vju ɪt fɹəm ðə pɝspɛktɪv ə ði ədʒɑz liɾɝz, aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk."

"Well," Egwene said, sipping her tea, "let me approach it with a clear mind. Best to view it from the perspective of the Ajah's leaders, I should think."

bɛn fɹaʊn feɪnli. "aɪ səpoʊz."

Bennae frowned faintly. "I suppose."

"naʊ, ɪn ðɪs sɪtʃueɪʃən jə dɪskɹaɪb, kən wi əsum ðət ðiz sikɹəts əv bɪn ɛntʃɹʌstɪd tə ði ədʒɑ fəɹ seɪfkipɪŋ? ɑ, ɡʊd. wɛl, fɹəm ðɛɹ pɝspɛktɪv, ɪmpɔɹɾənt ən kɛɹfəl plænz əv bɪn ʌpsɛt. θɪŋk ə haʊ ɪt mʌs lʊk. sʌmwʌn əz lɝn sikɹəts ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt. ðət wɪspɝz ʌv ə dɪstɝbɪŋ lik sʌmwɛɹ əmʌŋ jəɹ moʊs tʃɹʌstɪd mɛmbɝz."

"Now, in this situation you describe, can we assume that these secrets have been entrusted to the Ajah for safekeeping? Ah, good. Well, from their perspective, important and careful plans have been upset. Think of how it must look. Someone has learned secrets they should not. That whispers of a disturbing leak somewhere among your most trusted members."

bɛn peɪld. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kəd si ðæt."

Bennae paled. "I suppose I could see that."

"ðɛn ðə bɛst weɪ tə hændəl ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən wəd bi tufoʊld," ɛɡwin sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ sɪp ə ti. ɪt teɪstəd tɛɹəbəl. "fɝst, ðə liɾɝz ə ði ədʒɑ wəɾ əv tə bi ɹiəʃʊɹd. ðeɪ nid tə noʊ ðəɾ ɪt wɑzn ðɛɹ fɔl ðət ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən likt. ɪf aɪ wɝ ðə haɪpəθɛɾəkəl sɪstɝ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl - ən ɪf aɪd dʌn nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ - aɪd ɡoʊ tə ðɛm ən ɪkspleɪn. ðət weɪ ðeɪ kəd stɑp sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə wʌn u lɛɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən slɪp."

"Then the best way to handle the situation would be twofold," Egwene said, taking another sip of tea. It tasted terrible. "First, the leaders of the Ajah would have to be reassured. They need to know that it wasn't their fault that the information leaked. If I were the hypothetical sister in trouble - and if I'd done nothing wrong - I'd go to them and explain. That way they could stop searching for the one who let information slip."

"bʌt," bɛn sɛd, "ðæt pɹɑbli woʊn hɛlp ðə sɪstɝ - ðə haɪpəθɛɾəkəl wʌn ɪn tʃɹʌbəl - ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ pʌnɪʃməns."

"But," Bennae said, "that probably won't help the sister - the hypothetical one in trouble - get out of her punishments."

"ɪt kʊdn hɝt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "laɪkli, ʃiz biɪŋ 'pʌnɪʃt' tə kip əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ waɪl ði ədʒɑ liɾɝz sɝtʃ fəɹ ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ. wən ðeɪ noʊ ðəɹ ɪzənt wʌn, ðəl bi mɔɹ laɪkli tə lʊk ət ðə fɔlən sɪstɝz sɪtʃueɪʃən wɪð ɛmpəθi - pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli æftɝ ʃiz ɔfɝɾ əm ə səluʃən."

"It couldn't hurt," Egwene said. "Likely, she's being 'punished' to keep her out of the way while the Ajah leaders search for a traitor. When they know there isn't one, they'll be more likely to look at the fallen sister's situation with empathy - particularly after she's offered them a solution."

"səluʃən?" bɛn æskt. hɝ tikʌp sæɾ ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, əz ɪf fɝɡɑɾən. "ænd wɪtʃ səluʃən wəd jə ɔfɝ?"

"Solution?" Bennae asked. Her teacup sat in her fingers, as if forgotten. "And which solution would you offer?"

"ðə bɛst wʌn: kɑmpəɾəns. ɑbviəsli, səm pipəl əmʌŋ ði ədʒɑ noʊ ðiz sikɹəts. wɛl, ɪf ðɪs sɪstɝ wɝ tə pɹuv əɹ tʃɹʌstwɝðinəs ən əɹ keɪpəbɪləɾi, pɝhæps ðə liɾɝz ə hɝ ədʒɑ wəd ɹilaɪz ðə bɛs pleɪs fəɹ əɹ ɪz əz wʌn ə ðə kɛɹteɪkɝz ə ðə sikɹəts. ən izi səluʃən, ɪf jə kənsɪɾɝ ɪt."

"The best one: competence. Obviously, some people among the Ajah know these secrets. Well, if this sister were to prove her trustworthiness and her capability, perhaps the leaders of her Ajah would realize the best place for her is as one of the caretakers of the secrets. An easy solution, if you consider it."

bɛn sæt θɔtfəli, ə smɔl mʌmɪfaɪd fɪntʃ spɪnɪŋ sloʊli ɑn ɪts kɔɹd dɝɛkli əbʌv hɝ.

Bennae sat thoughtfully, a small mummified finch spinning slowly on its cord directly above her.

"jɛs, bʌt wɪl ɪt wɝk?"

"Yes, but will it work?"

"ɪɾ ɪz sɝɾənli bɛɾɝ ðən sɝvɪŋ ɪn səm fɝɡɑɾən stɔɹɹum kæɾəlɔɡɪŋ skɹoʊlz," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"It is certainly better than serving in some forgotten storeroom cataloguing scrolls," Egwene said.

"əndʒʌs pʌnɪʃmən səmtaɪmz kænɑt bi əvɔɪɾəd, bʌɾ ɪts bɛs nɛvɝ tə lɛɾ ʌðɝz fɝɡɛt ðəɾ ɪts əndʒʌst. ɪf ʃi sɪmpli æksɛps ðə weɪ pipəl tʃɹit hɝ, ðən ɪt woʊn bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ əsum ʃi dɪzɝvz ðə pəzɪʃən ðeɪv pleɪst əɹ ɪn." ən θæŋk ju, sɪlviænə, fəɹ ðət lɪɾəl bɪɾ ʌv ædvaɪs.

"Unjust punishment sometimes cannot be avoided, but it is best never to let others forget that it is unjust. If she simply accepts the way people treat her, then it won't be long before they assume she deserves the position they've placed her in." And thank you, Silviana, for that little bit of advice.

"jɛs," bɛn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ. "jɛs, aɪ də səpoʊz ðət jə ɑɹ kɝɛkt."

"Yes," Bennae said, nodding. "Yes, I do suppose that you are correct."

"aɪ æm ɔlweɪz wɪlɪŋ tə hɛlp, bɛn," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɪn ə sɑftɝ vɔɪs, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə hɝ ti. "ɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, haɪpəθɛɾəkəl sɪtʃueɪʃənz."

"I am always willing to help, Bennae," Egwene said in a softer voice, turning back to her tea. "In, of course, hypothetical situations."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɛɡwin wɝid ðət ʃid ɡɔn tu fɑɹ ɪn kɔlɪŋ ðə bɹaʊn baɪ hɝ neɪm.

For a moment, Egwene worried that she'd gone too far in calling the Brown by her name.

haʊɛvɝ, bɛn mɛɾ əɹ aɪz, ðən æktʃəli  wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə baʊ hɝ hɛd dʒʌst slaɪtli ɪn θæŋks.

However, Bennae met her eyes, then actually went so far as to bow her head just slightly in thanks.

ɪf ði aʊɝ spɛnt wɪð bɛn hæd bɪn aɪsəleɪɾəd, ɛɡwin wəd stɪl əv faʊn ɪt ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl.

If the hour spent with Bennae had been isolated, Egwene would still have found it remarkable.

haʊɛvɝ, ʃi wɑz ʃɑk tə dɪskʌvɝ - əpɑn livɪŋ bɛnz lɛɹ ʌv ə ɹum - ə nɑvəs weɪɾɪŋ wɪð ə mɛsədʒ ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ əɹ tə ətɛnd nəɡɔɹə, ə waɪt sɪstɝ. ɛɡwin stɪl hæd taɪm bɪfɔɹ əɹ miɾɪŋ wɪð maɪdɑni, soʊ ʃi wɛnt. ʃi kʊdn ɪɡnɔɹ ə sʌmənz fɹəm ə sɪstɝ, ðoʊ ʃi wəɾ əndaʊɾɪdli hæv tə də ɛkstʃɹə tʃɔɹz leɪɾɝ tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ skɪpɪŋ ðə flɔɹ skɹʌbɪŋ.

However, she was shocked to discover - upon leaving Bennae's lair of a room - a novice waiting with a message instructing her to attend Nagora, a White sister. Egwene still had time before her meeting with Meidani, so she went. She couldn't ignore a summons from a sister, though she would undoubtedly have to do extra chores later to make up for skipping the floor scrubbing.

ət ðə miɾɪŋ wɪð nəɡɔɹə, ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf biɪŋ tʃɹeɪn ɪn lɑdʒɪk - ən ðə "lɑdʒɪkəl pʌzəlz" pɹizɛntəd saʊndəd vɛɹi sɪməlɝ tə ə ɹɪkwɛs fəɹ hɛlp ɪn dilɪŋ wɪð ə wɔɹɾɝ u wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd wɪð ɪz ɪnkɹisɪŋ eɪdʒ ən ɪnəbɪlɪɾi tə faɪt. ɛɡwin ɡeɪv wʌt hɛlp ʃi kʊd, wɪtʃ nəɡɔɹə dɪklɛɹd tə bi "lɑdʒɪk wɪθaʊt flɔ" bɪfɔɹ ɹilisɪŋ hɝ. æftɝ ðæt, ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ mɛsədʒ, ðɪs wʌn fɹəm swænə, wʌn ə ðə sɪɾɝz ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ.

At the meeting with Nagora, Egwene found herself being trained in logic - and the "logical puzzles" presented sounded very similar to a request for help in dealing with a Warder who was growing frustrated with his increasing age and inability to fight. Egwene gave what help she could, which Nagora declared to be "logic without flaw" before releasing her. After that, there was another message, this one from Suana, one of the Sitters of the Yellow Ajah.

eɪ sɪɾɝ! ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɛɡwin hæd bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə ətɛnd wʌn ə ðɛm. ɛɡwin hɝid tə ði əpɔɪnmənt ən wɑz ədmɪɾəd baɪ ə meɪdsɝvənt. swænəz kɔɹɾɝz lʊk mɔɹ laɪk ə ɡɑɹɾən ðən pɹɑpɝ ɹumz. əz ə sɪɾɝ, swænə kəd dɪmæn kɔɹɾɝz wɪð wɪndoʊz, ən ʃi meɪd fʊl jus ə hɝ ɪnsɛt bælkəni əz ən ɝb ɡɑɹɾən. bʌt bɪɑn ðæt, ʃi hæd mɪɹɝz pəzɪʃən tə ɹəflɛk laɪɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum, wɪtʃ wɑz oʊvɝɡɹoʊn wɪð smɔl pɑɾɪd tʃɹiz, ʃɹʌbz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪn lɑɹdʒ beɪsənz ə ɝθ, ən ivən ə smɔl ɡɑɹɾən fəɹ kæɹəts ən ɹæɾɪʃɪz. ɛɡwin noʊɾəst wɪð dɪsplɛʒɝ ə smɔl paɪl ə ɹɑɾɪd təbɝz ɪn wʌn kənteɪnɝ, laɪkli dʒʌs hɑɹvəstəd bʌt sʌmhaʊ ɔlɹɛɾi spɔɪld.

A Sitter! It was the first time Egwene had been ordered to attend one of them. Egwene hurried to the appointment and was admitted by a maidservant. Suana's quarters looked more like a garden than proper rooms. As a Sitter, Suana could demand quarters with windows, and she made full use of her inset balcony as an herb garden. But beyond that, she had mirrors positioned to reflect light into the room, which was overgrown with small potted trees, shrubs growing in large basins of earth, and even a small garden for carrots and radishes. Egwene noticed with displeasure a small pile of rotted tubers in one container, likely just harvested but somehow already spoiled.

ðə ɹum smɛl stʃɹɔŋli ʌv bæzəl, θaɪm ən ə dʌzən ʌðɝ ɝbz. dɪspaɪt ðə pɹɑbləmz ɪn ðə taʊɝ, dɪspaɪt ðə ɹɑɾɪd plæns, ʃi wɑz buid baɪ ðə sɛn ə laɪf ɪn ðə ɹum - ðə fɹɛʃli tɝn ɝθ ən ɡɹoʊɪŋ plæns. ən nɪneɪiv kəmpleɪn ðət ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə jusfəlnəs ə ɝbz! ɪf oʊnli ʃi kəd spɛn səm taɪm wɪð stɝɾi, skwɛɹ-feɪst swænə.

The room smelled strongly of basil, thyme and a dozen other herbs. Despite the problems in the Tower, despite the rotted plants, she was buoyed by the scent of life in the room - the freshly turned earth and growing plants. And Nynaeve complained that the sisters in the White Tower ignored the usefulness of herbs! If only she could spend some time with sturdy, square-faced Suana.

ɛɡwin faʊn ðə wʊmən ɹɪmɑɹkəbli plɛzənt. swænə ɹæn əɹ θɹu ə sɪɹiz ʌv wivz, mɛni ʌv əm ɹɪleɪɾɪd tə hilɪŋ, wɛɹ ɛɡwin hæd nɛvɝ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ʃoʊn. stɪl, hɝ skɪl mʌst əv ɪmpɹɛs ðə sɪɾɝ, fəɹ mɪdweɪ θɹu ðə lɛsən - ɛɡwin siɾəd ɑn ə kʊʃən stul bɪtwin tu pɑɾɪd tʃɹiz, swænə sɪɾɪŋ mɔɹ pɹɑpɝli ɪn ə stɪf lɛðɝ-kʌvɝd tʃɛɹ - ðə toʊn ə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən tʃeɪnʒd.

Egwene found the woman remarkably pleasant. Suana ran her through a series of weaves, many of them related to Healing, where Egwene had never particularly shone. Still, her skill must have impressed the Sitter, for midway through the lesson - Egwene seated on a cushioned stool between two potted trees, Suana sitting more properly in a stiff leather-covered chair - the tone of the conversation changed.

"wi ʃəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk tə hæv jə ɪn ðə jɛloʊ, aɪ θɪŋk," ðə wʊmən sɛd.

"We should very much like to have you in the Yellow, I think," the woman said.

ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd. "aɪv nɛvɝ ʃoʊn pɝtɪkjəlɝ skɪl fəɹ hilɪŋ."

Egwene started. "I've never shown particular skill for Healing."

"biɪŋ ə ðə jɛloʊ ɪzən əbaʊt skɪl, tʃaɪld," swænə sɛd. "ɪts əbaʊt pæʃən. ɪf jə lʌv tə meɪk θɪŋz wɛl, tə fɪks ðət wɪtʃ ɪz bɹoʊkən, ðəɹ wəd bi ə pɝpəs fəɹ jə hɪɹ."

"Being of the Yellow isn't about skill, child," Suana said. "It's about passion. If you love to make things well, to fix that which is broken, there would be a purpose for you here."

"maɪ θæŋks," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn əz noʊ ədʒɑ."

"My thanks," Egwene said. "But the Amyrlin has no Ajah."

"jɛs, bʌt ʃiz ɹeɪz fɹəm wʌn. kənsɪɾɝ ɪt, ɛɡwin. aɪ θɪŋk jə wəd faɪn ə ɡʊd hoʊm hɪɹ."

"Yes, but she's raised from one. Consider it, Egwene. I think you would find a good home here."

ɪt wɑz ə ʃɑkɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən. swænə ɑbviəsli dɪdn kənsɪɾɝ ɛɡwin ði æmɪɝlɪn, bʌt ðə mɪɹ fæk ðət ʃi wɑz ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ ɛɡwin tə hɝ ədʒɑ sɛd sʌmθɪŋ. ɪt mɛnt ʃi æksɛptɪɾ ɛɡwinz lədʒɪɾəməsi, ət lis tə səm dɪɡɹi, əz ə sɪstɝ.

It was a shocking conversation. Suana obviously didn't consider Egwene the Amyrlin, but the mere fact that she was recruiting Egwene to her Ajah said something. It meant she accepted Egwene's legitimacy, at least to some degree, as a sister.

"swænə," ɛɡwin sɛd, tɛstɪŋ haʊ fɑɹ ʃi kəd pʊʃ ðət sɛns ə lədʒɪɾəməsi, "hæv ðə sɪɾɝz spoʊkən ʌv wʌt tə də əbaʊt ðə tɛntʃənz bɪtwin ði ədʒəz?"

"Suana," Egwene said, testing how far she could push that sense of legitimacy, "have the Sitters spoken of what to do about the tensions between the Ajahs?"

"aɪ doʊn si wʌt kən bi dʌn," swænə ɹɪplaɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əɹ oʊvɝɡɹoʊn bælkəni. "ɪf ði ʌðɝ ədʒəz əv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə si ðə jɛloʊ əz ðɛɹ ɛnəmi, ðən aɪ kænɑt kəmpɛl əm tə bi lɛs fulɪʃ."

"I don't see what can be done," Suana replied, glancing toward her overgrown balcony. "If the other Ajahs have decided to see the Yellow as their enemy, then I cannot compel them to be less foolish."

ðeɪ laɪkli seɪ ðə seɪm əbaʊt ju, ɛɡwin θɔt, bʌt sɛd, "sʌmwʌn mʌs meɪk ðə fɝst stɛps. ðə ʃɛl ə dɪstʃɹʌst ɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ soʊ θɪk ðət sun ɪɾəl bi hɑɹd tə kɹæk. pɝhæps ɪf səm ə ðə sɪɾɝz ə dɪfɹən ədʒəz bɪɡæn teɪkɪŋ milz təɡɛðɝ, əɹ wɝ sin tʃɹævlɪŋ ðə hɔlweɪz ɪn wʌn ənʌðɝz kʌmpəni, ɪt wəd pɹuv ɪnstʃɹʌktɪv fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taʊɝ."

They likely say the same about you, Egwene thought, but said, "Someone must make the first steps. The shell of distrust is growing so thick that soon it will be hard to crack. Perhaps if some of the Sitters of different Ajahs began taking meals together, or were seen traveling the hallways in one another's company, it would prove instructive for the rest of the Tower."

"pɝhæps . . ." swænə sɛd.

"Perhaps . . ." Suana said.

"ðeɪ ɑɹən jəɹ ɛnəmiz, swænə," ɛɡwin sɛd, lɛɾɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs ɡɹoʊ mɔɹ fɝm.

"They aren't your enemies, Suana," Egwene said, letting her voice grow more firm.

ðə wʊmən fɹaʊn əɾ ɛɡwin, əz ɪf ɹilaɪzɪŋ sʌɾənli hu ʃi wɑz teɪkɪŋ ædvaɪs fɹʌm. "wɛl, ðɛn, aɪ θɪŋk ɪts bɛs ðət jə ɹæn əlɔŋ. aɪm sɝɾən ðəɹ ɪz ə ɡɹeɪt dil fəɹ jə tə də tədeɪ."

The woman frowned at Egwene, as if realizing suddenly who she was taking advice from. "Well, then, I think it's best that you ran along. I'm certain there is a great deal for you to do today."

ɛɡwin lɛt hɝsɛlf aʊt, kɛɹfəli əvɔɪɾɪŋ dʒɹupɪŋ bɹæntʃəz ən klʌstɝz ə pɑts. wʌns ʃi lɛf ðə jɛloʊ sɛktɝ ə ðə taʊɝ ən kəlɛktəɾ əɹ ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ətɛndəns, ʃi ɹilaɪz sʌmθɪŋ. ʃid ɡɔn θɹu ɔl θɹi miɾɪŋz wɪθaʊt biɪŋ əsaɪn ə sɪŋɡəl pʌnɪʃmənt. ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt tə θɪŋk ə ðæt. ʃiɾ ivən kɔl tu ʌv əm baɪ neɪm dɝɛkli tə ðɛɹ feɪsəz!

Egwene let herself out, carefully avoiding drooping branches and clusters of pots. Once she left the Yellow sector of the Tower and collected her Red Ajah attendants, she realized something. She'd gone through all three meetings without being assigned a single punishment. She wasn't certain what to think of that. She'd even called two of them by name directly to their faces!

ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ tə æksɛp hɝ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðət wɑz oʊnli ə smɔl pɑɹɾ ə ðə bæɾəl. ðə lɑɹdʒɝ pɑɹt wɑz meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən ðə waɪt taʊɝ sɝvaɪv ðə stʃɹeɪnz ɪleɪɾə wɑz pleɪsɪŋ əpɑn ɪt.

They were coming to accept her. Unfortunately, that was only a small part of the battle. The larger part was making certain the White Tower survived the strains Elaida was placing upon it.

maɪdɑniz kɔɹɾɝz wɝ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli kʌmftəɹbəl ən hoʊmi. ɛɡwin hæɾ ɔlweɪz vjud ðə ɡɹeɪz əz sɪməlɝ tə ðə waɪts, lækɪŋ pæʃən, pɝfək dɪpləmæts u dɪdn əv taɪm fəɹ pɝsənəl ɪmoʊʃənz əɹ fɹɪvələɾiz.

Meidani's quarters were surprisingly comfortable and homey. Egwene had always viewed the Grays as similar to the Whites, lacking passion, perfect diplomats who didn't have time for personal emotions or frivolities.

ðiz ɹumz, haʊɛvɝ, hɪntəɾ əɾ ə wʊmən u lʌv tə tʃɹævəl. mæps hʌŋ wɪðɪn dɛləkət fɹeɪmz, sɛntɝɾ ɑn ðə wɔlz laɪk pɹaɪz pisəz ʌv ɑɹt. ə pɛɹ ʌv il spɪɹz hʌŋ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ʌv wʌn mæp; ənʌðɝ wɑz ə mæp ə ðə si foʊk aɪlənz. waɪl mɛni maɪɾ əv ɑptɪd fəɹ ðə pɔɹsələn kipseɪks ðət wɝ soʊ kɑmənli əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð ðə si foʊk, maɪdɑni hæɾ ə smɔl kəlɛkʃən ʌv ɪɹɪŋz ən peɪntəd ʃɛlz, kɛɹfəli fɹeɪmd ən dɪspleɪd, əlɔŋ wɪð ə smɔl plæk bɪniθ lɪstɪŋ deɪts ə kəlɛkʃən.

These rooms, however, hinted at a woman who loved to travel. Maps hung within delicate frames, centered on the walls like prized pieces of art. A pair of Aiel spears hung on either side of one map; another was a map of the Sea Folk islands. While many might have opted for the porcelain keepsakes that were so commonly associated with the Sea Folk, Meidani had a small collection of earrings and painted shells, carefully framed and displayed, along with a small plaque beneath listing dates of collection.

ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɑz laɪk ə mjuziəm dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə wʌn pɝsənz dʒɝniz. ən ɔltɑɹən mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf, sɛt wɪð fɔɹ twɪŋkəlɪŋ ɹubiz, hʌŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl kɛɹhinɪn bænɝ ən ə ʃaɪnɝən sɔɹd.

The sitting room was like a museum dedicated to one person's journeys. An Altaran marriage knife, set with four twinkling rubies, hung beside a small Cairhienin banner and a Shienaran sword.

itʃ hæɾ ə smɔl plæk ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ɪts səɡnɪfɪkəns. ðə mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf, fəɹ ɪnstəns, hæd bɪn pɹizɛntəd tə maɪdɑni fəɹ əɹ hɛlp ɪn sɛɾəlɪŋ ə dɪspjut bɪtwin tu haʊsəz oʊvɝ ðə dɛθ ʌv ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪmpɔɹɾənt lændoʊnɝ. hɪz waɪf hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ðə naɪf əz ə toʊkən ə θæŋks.

Each had a small plaque explaining its significance. The marriage knife, for instance, had been presented to Meidani for her help in settling a dispute between two houses over the death of a particularly important landowner. His wife had given her the knife as a token of thanks.

hu wʊɾə θɔt ðət ðə kaʊɝɪŋ wʊmən ə ðə dɪnɝ ə fju wiks bæk wəɾ əv sətʃ ə pɹaʊd kəlɛkʃən? ðə ɹʌɡ ɪtsɛlf wɑz leɪbəld, ðə ɡɪft ʌv ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ u hæd pɝtʃəst ɪɾ ɑn ðə kloʊz dɑks ə ʃɑɹə, ðən bɪstoʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn maɪdɑni ɪn θæŋks fəɹ hilɪŋ ɪz dɔɾɝ. ɪt wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ dɪzaɪn, woʊvən fɹəm wʌt sim tə bi taɪni, daɪd ɹidz, wɪð tʌfs ʌv ən ɪɡzɑɾɪk ɡɹeɪ fɝ tʃɹɪmɪŋ ði ɛdʒəz. ðə pæɾɝn dɪpɪktəɾ ɪɡzɑɾɪk kɹitʃɝz wɪð lɔŋ nɛks.

Who would have thought that the cowering woman of the dinner a few weeks back would have such a proud collection? The rug itself was labeled, the gift of a trader who had purchased it on the closed docks of Shara, then bestowed it on Meidani in thanks for Healing his daughter. It was of strange design, woven from what seemed to be tiny, dyed reeds, with tufts of an exotic gray fur trimming the edges. The pattern depicted exotic creatures with long necks.

maɪdɑni hɝsɛlf sæɾ ɑn ə kjʊɹiəs tʃɛɹ meɪd fɹəm woʊvən wɪkɝ baʊz, kɹæftɪd tə lʊk laɪk ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ θɪkɪɾ ə bɹæntʃəz ðət dʒʌs hæpən tə teɪk ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tʃɛɹ. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn hɔɹəbli aʊɾ ə pleɪs ɪn ɛni ʌðɝ ɹum ɪn ðə taʊɝ, bʌɾ ɪt fɪt wɪðɪn ðiz kɔɹɾɝz, wɛɹ itʃ aɪɾəm wɑz dɪfɹənt, nʌn ə ðɛm ɹɪleɪɾɪd jɛt sʌmhaʊ ɔl kənɛktəd wɪð ðə kɑmən θim ʌv ɡɪfs ɹəsiv dʊɹɪŋ tʃɹævəlz.

Meidani herself sat on a curious chair made from woven wicker boughs, crafted to look like a growing thicket of branches that just happened to take the shape of a chair. It would have been horribly out of place in any other room in the Tower, but it fit within these quarters, where each item was different, none of them related yet somehow all connected with the common theme of gifts received during travels.

ðə ɡɹeɪz əpɪɹəns wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn dʊɹɪŋ ðə dɪnɝ wɪð ɪleɪɾə. ɪnstɛɾ ə ðə loʊ-kʌt kʌlɝfəl dʒɹɛs, ʃi wɔɹ ə haɪ-nɛkt ɡaʊn ə pleɪn waɪt, lɔŋ ən teɪpɝɪŋ, kʌɾ əz ɪf tə dimfəsaɪz əɹ bʊzəm. hɝ dip ɡoʊldən hɛɹ wɑz ʌp ɪn ə bʌn, ən ʃi dɪdnt wɛɹ ə sɪŋɡəl ɡlɪmɝ ə dʒuəlɹi. wɑz ðə kɑntʃɹæst ɪntɛnʃənəl?

The Gray's appearance was surprisingly different from what it had been during the dinner with Elaida. Instead of the low-cut colorful dress, she wore a high-necked gown of plain white, long and tapering, cut as if to deemphasize her bosom. Her deep golden hair was up in a bun, and she didn't wear a single glimmer of jewelry. Was the contrast intentional?

"ju tʊk jəɹ taɪm sʌmənɪŋ mi," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"You took your time summoning me," Egwene said.

"aɪ dɪdnt wɑnə əpɪɹ səspɪʃəs bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn," maɪdɑni sɛɾ əz ɛɡwin kɹɔs ði ɪɡzɑɾɪk ʃɑɹə ɹʌɡ. "bɪsaɪdz, aɪm stɪl nɑt sɝɾən haʊ aɪ ɹəɡɑɹd ju."

"I didn't want to appear suspicious before the Amyrlin," Meidani said as Egwene crossed the exotic Shara rug. "Besides, I'm still not certain how I regard you."

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ jə ɹəɡɑɹd mi," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ivənli, siɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɑn ən oʊvɝsaɪzd oʊk tʃɛɹ, bɛɹɪŋ ə plæk ðəɾ aɪdɛntəfaɪɾ ɪɾ əz ə ɡɪft fɹəm ə mʌnilɛndɝ ɪn tɛɹ. "æn æmɪɝlɪn nidz nɑt ðə ɹəɡɑɹɾ ə ðoʊz u fɑloʊ hɝ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃiz oʊbeɪd."

"I don't care how you regard me," Egwene said evenly, seating herself on an oversized oak chair, bearing a plaque that identified it as a gift from a moneylender in Tear. "An Amyrlin needs not the regard of those who follow her, so long as she is obeyed."

"juv bɪn kæptʃɝɾ ən oʊvɝθɹoʊn."

"You've been captured and overthrown."

ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, miɾɪŋ maɪdɑniz ɡeɪz. "kæptʃɝd, tʃɹu."

Egwene raised an eyebrow, meeting Meidani's gaze. "Captured, true."

"ðə hɔl əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəlz wɪl əv tʃoʊzən ə nu æmɪɝlɪn baɪ naʊ."

"The Hall among the rebels will have chosen a new Amyrlin by now."

"aɪ hæpən tə noʊ ðət ðeɪv nɑt."

"I happen to know that they have not."

maɪdɑni hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɹɪvilɪŋ ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə kɑntækt wɪð ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ə ɡæmbəl, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi kʊdn sɪkjʊɹ ðə lɔɪəlti ʌv maɪdɑni ən ðə spaɪz, ðən ʃi wɑz ɑn ʃeɪki ɡɹaʊn ɪndid.

Meidani hesitated. Revealing the existence of contact with the rebel Aes Sedai was a gamble, but if she couldn't secure the loyalty of Meidani and the spies, then she was on shaky ground indeed.

ɛɡwin hæɾ əsum ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi izi tə ɡeɪn ðə wʊmənz səpɔɹt, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ fɹaɪɾənd maɪdɑni hæd bɪn ət sʌpɝ. bʌɾ ɪt sim ðət ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑɾ əz izəli kaʊɾ əz ɪt hæɾ əpɪɹd.

Egwene had assumed that it would be easy to gain the woman's support, considering how frightened Meidani had been at supper. But it seemed that the woman was not as easily cowed as it had appeared.

"wɛl," maɪdɑni sɛd. "ivən ɪf ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹu, jə mʌs noʊ ðət ðeɪ pɪk jə tə bi ə fɪɡjɝhɛd.

"Well," Meidani said. "Even if that is true, you must know that they picked you to be a figurehead.

ə pʌpət tə bi mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd."

A puppet to be manipulated."

ɛɡwin hɛl ðə wʊmənz ɡeɪz.

Egwene held the woman's gaze.

"ju hæv noʊ ɹil əθɔɹəɾi," maɪdɑni sɛd, vɔɪs weɪvɝɪŋ slaɪtli.

"You have no real authority," Meidani said, voice wavering slightly.

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt lʊk əweɪ. maɪdɑni stʌɾid hɝ, bɹaʊ ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ sloʊli, stɛp baɪ stɛp, fɝoʊz əpɪɹɪŋ əkɹɔs əɹ smuð, eɪdʒləs ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs. ʃi sɝtʃt ɛɡwinz aɪz, laɪk ə meɪsən sɝtʃɪŋ ə pis ə stoʊn fəɹ flɔz bɪfɔɹ sɛɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn pleɪs. wʌt ʃi faʊn sim tə kənfjuz əɹ fɝðɝ.

Egwene did not look away. Meidani studied her, brow wrinkling slowly, step by step, furrows appearing across her smooth, ageless Aes Sedai face. She searched Egwene's eyes, like a mason searching a piece of stone for flaws before setting it in place. What she found seemed to confuse her further.

"naʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd, əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt dʒʌs bɪn kwɛstʃənd, "ju wɪl tɛl mi pɹɪsaɪsli waɪ juv nɑt flɛd ðə taʊɝ. waɪl aɪ də bɪliv ðət jəɹ spaɪɪŋ ɑn ɪleɪɾə ɪz væljəbəl, jə mʌs noʊ haʊ mʌtʃ deɪnʒɝ jə ɑɹ ɪn naʊ ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə ɪz əwɛɹ ə jəɹ tʃɹu əlidʒəns. waɪ nɑt liv?"

"Now," Egwene said, as if she had not just been questioned, "you will tell me precisely why you have not fled the Tower. While I do believe that your spying on Elaida is valuable, you must know how much danger you are in now that Elaida is aware of your true allegiance. Why not leave?"

"aɪ . . . kænɑt seɪ," maɪdɑni sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ əweɪ.

"I . . . cannot say," Meidani said, glancing away.

"aɪm kəmændɪŋ jə əz jəɹ æmɪɝlɪn."

"I'm commanding you as your Amyrlin."

"aɪ stɪl kænɑt seɪ." maɪdɑni lʊk daʊn ət ðə flɔɹ, əz ɪf əʃeɪmd.

"I still cannot say." Meidani looked down at the floor, as if ashamed.

kjʊɹiəs, ɛɡwin θɔt, haɪɾɪŋ əɹ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. "ɪɾ ɪz ɑbviəs ðət jə də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə ɡɹævəɾi ʌv əɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən. iðɝ jə æksɛp maɪ əθɔɹəɾi, əɹ jə æksɛp ðəɾ ʌv ɪleɪɾə. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ mɪɾəl ɡɹaʊnd, maɪdɑni. ən aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðɪs: ɪf ɪleɪɾə ɹɪteɪnz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, jəl faɪn əɹ tʃɹitmən ə ðoʊz ʃi siz əz tʃɹeɪɾɝz tə bi kwaɪɾ ənplɛzənt."

Curious, Egwene thought, hiding her frustration. "It is obvious that you do not understand the gravity of our situation. Either you accept my authority, or you accept that of Elaida. There is no middle ground, Meidani. And I promise you this: If Elaida retains the Amyrlin Seat, you will find her treatment of those she sees as traitors to be quite unpleasant."

maɪdɑni kəntɪnjud tə lʊk daʊn. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ɪnɪʃəl ɹɪzɪstəns, ɪt sim ðət ʃi hæd lɪɾəl stʃɹɛŋkθ ʌv wɪl ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ.

Meidani continued to look down. Despite her initial resistance, it seemed that she had little strength of will remaining.

"aɪ si." ɛɡwin ɹoʊz tə hɝ fit. "juv bɪtʃɹeɪɾ ʌs, hævən ju? dɪd jə ɡoʊ tə ɪleɪɾəz saɪd bɪfɔɹ jə wɝ ɪkspoʊzd əɹ æftɝ bioʊnɪnz kənfɛʃən?"

"I see." Egwene rose to her feet. "You've betrayed us, haven't you? Did you go to Elaida's side before you were exposed or after Beonin's confession?"

maɪdɑni lʊkt ʌp ɪmiɾiətli. "wʌt? noʊ! aɪ nɛvɝ bɪtʃɹeɪɾ əɹ kɑz!" ʃi sim sɪkənd, feɪs peɪl, maʊð ə θɪn laɪn. "haʊ kəd jə θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪd səpɔɹt ðət hɔɹəd wʊmən? aɪ heɪt wʌt ʃiz dʌn tə ðə taʊɝ."

Meidani looked up immediately. "What? No! I never betrayed our cause!" She seemed sickened, face pale, mouth a thin line. "How could you think that I'd support that horrid woman? I hate what she has done to the Tower."

wɛl, ðət wɑz stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝɾ ɪnʌf; lɪɾəl ɹum tə wɪɡəl ɝaʊn ðə θɹi oʊðz ɪn ðoʊz steɪtməns. iðɝ maɪdɑni wɑz tʃɹu əɹ ʃi wɑz blæk - ðoʊ ɛɡwin hæd dɪfəkəlti bɪlivɪŋ ðəɾ ə blæk sɪstɝ wəɾ ɛndeɪnʒɝ hɝsɛlf baɪ tɛlɪŋ ə laɪ ðət kəd bi ɪkspoʊzd wɪð sətʃ ɹɛləɾɪv iz.

Well, that was straightforward enough; little room to wiggle around the Three Oaths in those statements. Either Meidani was true or she was Black - though Egwene had difficulty believing that a Black sister would endanger herself by telling a lie that could be exposed with such relative ease.

"waɪ nɑt ɹʌn, ðɛn?" ɛɡwin æskt. "waɪ steɪ?"

"Why not run, then?" Egwene asked. "Why stay?"

maɪdɑni ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ kænɑt seɪ."

Meidani shook her head. "I cannot say."

ɛɡwin tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ði ɪntaɪɝ kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɪɹəteɪɾəd hɝ. "wɪl jə ət lis tɛl mi waɪ jə teɪk dɪnɝ wɪð ɪleɪɾə soʊ ɔfən? ʃʊɹli ɪts nɑt kəz jə ɛndʒɔɪ sətʃ tʃɹitmənt."

Egwene took a deep breath. Something about the entire conversation irritated her. "Will you at least tell me why you take dinner with Elaida so often? Surely it's not because you enjoy such treatment."

maɪdɑni blʌʃt. "ɪleɪɾə ən aɪ wɝ pɪloʊ-fɹɛnz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ deɪz əz nɑvəsɪz. ði ʌðɝz dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ ɪf aɪ wɝ tə ɹɪnu ðə ɹileɪʃənʃɪp, pɝhæps ɪt wəd lɛd tə maɪ ɡeɪnɪŋ væljəbəl ɪnfɝmeɪʃən."

Meidani blushed. "Elaida and I were pillow-friends during our days as novices. The others decided that if I were to renew the relationship, perhaps it would lead to my gaining valuable information."

ɛɡwin foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts. "ɪt simz ɹɛkləs tə əsum ʃi wəd tʃɹʌs ju.

Egwene folded her arms beneath her breasts. "It seems reckless to assume she would trust you.

haʊɛvɝ, ɪleɪɾəz θɝs fəɹ paʊɝ ɪz ɡaɪɾɪŋ əɹ tə meɪk ɹɛkləs muvz ə hɝ oʊn, soʊ pɝhæps ðə plæn wɑz nɑt kəmplitli ɪl ædvaɪzd. ɹəɡɑɹdləs, ʃɪl nɛvɝ dʒɹɔ jə ɪndə hɝ kɑnfəɾəns naʊ ðət ʃi noʊz ə jəɹ tʃɹu ælidʒiænsɪz."

However, Elaida's thirst for power is guiding her to make reckless moves of her own, so perhaps the plan was not completely ill advised. Regardless, she'll never draw you into her confidence now that she knows of your true allegiances."

"aɪ noʊ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ aɪ ʃʊdn lɛɾ ɑn ðəɾ aɪm əwɛɹ ə hɝ nɑlədʒ. ɪf aɪ wɝ tə bæk əweɪ naʊ, ɪt wəd lɛɾ ɑn ðət wiv bɪn wɔɹnd - ən ðəɾ ɪz wʌn ə ðə pɹɛʃəs fju ɛdʒəz wi naʊ hoʊld."

"I know. But it was decided that I shouldn't let on that I'm aware of her knowledge. If I were to back away now, it would let on that we've been warned - and that is one of the precious few edges we now hold."

pɹɛʃəs fju ɪnʌf ðət ʃi ʃəɾ əv dʒʌst ɹʌn fɹəm ðə taʊɝ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi ɡeɪn baɪ steɪɪŋ. waɪ, ðɛn? sʌmθɪŋ wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ðə wʊmən bæk, ɪt simd. sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ.

Precious few enough that she should have just run from the Tower. There was nothing to be gained by staying. Why, then? Something was holding the woman back, it seemed. Something strong.

ə pɹɑməs?

A promise?

"maɪdɑni," ɛɡwin sɛd, "aɪ nid tə noʊ wʌɾ ɪts ðət jə ɑɹən tɛlɪŋ mi."

"Meidani," Egwene said, "I need to know what it is that you aren't telling me."

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd; ʃi ɔlmoʊs lʊkt əfɹeɪd. laɪt! ɛɡwin θɔt. aɪ woʊn də tə hɝ wʌɾ ɪleɪɾə dʌz ðoʊz ivnɪŋz ət sʌpɝ.

She shook her head; she almost looked afraid. Light! Egwene thought. I won't do to her what Elaida does those evenings at supper.

ɛɡwin sæt bæk daʊn. "stʃɹeɪɾən jəɹ bæk, maɪdɑni. jəɹ nɑt səm sɪmpɝɪŋ nɑvəs.

Egwene sat back down. "Straighten your back, Meidani. You're not some simpering novice.

jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. stɑɹɾ æktɪŋ laɪk wʌn."

You're Aes Sedai. Start acting like one."

ðə wʊmən lʊkt ʌp, aɪz flæʃɪŋ ət ðə tɔnt. ɛɡwin nɑɾəd əpɹuvɪŋli. "wi wɪl mɛn ðə dæmədʒ ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə hæz dʌn, ən əl sɪɾ ɪn maɪ ɹaɪtfəl pleɪs əz æmɪɝlɪn. bʌt wɪv wɝk tə du."

The woman looked up, eyes flashing at the taunt. Egwene nodded approvingly. "We will mend the damage that Elaida has done, and I will sit in my rightful place as Amyrlin. But we have work to do."

"aɪ kænt - "

"I can't - "

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ju kæn tɛl mi wʌɾ ɪz ɹɔŋ. aɪ səspɛk ðət ðə θɹi oʊðz ɑɹ ɪnvɑlvd, ðoʊ laɪt noʊz haʊ. wi kən wɝk ɝaʊn ðə pɹɑbləm. jə kæn tɛl mi waɪ juv ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ. bʌt kən jə ʃoʊ mi?"

"Yes," Egwene said. "You can't tell me what is wrong. I suspect that the Three Oaths are involved, though Light knows how. We can work around the problem. You can't tell me why you've remained in the Tower. But can you show me?"

maɪdɑni kɑkt əɹ hɛd. "aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ. aɪ kəd teɪk jə tə - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli. jɛs, wʌn ə ði oʊðz wɑz fɔɹsəbli pɹɪvɛntɪŋ əɹ fɹəm kəntɪnjuɪŋ. "aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ʃoʊ ju," maɪdɑni fɪnɪʃt leɪmli. "aɪm nɑt sɝɾən."
