Meidani cocked her head. "I'm not sure. I could take you to - " She cut off abruptly. Yes, one of the Oaths was forcibly preventing her from continuing. "I might be able to show you," Meidani finished lamely. "I'm not certain."

"ðɛn lɛts faɪn aʊt. haʊ deɪnʒɝəs wɪl ɪt bi ɪf ðoʊz ɹɛd hænlɝz ə maɪn fɑloʊ ʌs?"

"Then let's find out. How dangerous will it be if those Red handlers of mine follow us?"

maɪdɑni peɪld. "deɪnʒɝəs."

Meidani paled. "Dangerous."

"ðɛn wɪl əv tə liv əm bɪhaɪnd," ɛɡwin sɛd, æbsənli tæpɪŋ ði ɑɹmɹɛst ə hɝ oʊvɝsaɪzd oʊk tʃɛɹ wɪð wʌn neɪl əz ʃi θɔt. "wi kəd liv ðə ɡɹeɪ sɛkʃən ə ðə taʊɝ baɪ ənʌðɝ weɪ, bʌɾ ɪf wəɹ sin, ɪt kəd ɹeɪz dɪfəkəl kwɛstʃənz."

"Then we'll have to leave them behind," Egwene said, absently tapping the armrest of her oversized oak chair with one nail as she thought. "We could leave the Gray section of the Tower by another way, but if we are seen, it could raise difficult questions."

"ðɛɹ əv bɪn ə lɑɾ ə ɹɛdz lɝkɪŋ nɪɹ ði ɛntʃɹənsəz ən ɛɡzɪts ʌv əɹ kɔɹɾɝz," maɪdɑni sɛd. "aɪ səspɛkt ɔl ə ði ədʒəz ɑɹ wɑtʃɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ laɪk ðæt. ɪɾəl bi vɛɹi dɪfəkəl tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ noʊɾəst. ðeɪ wʊdn fɑloʊ mi əloʊn, bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ si jə . . ."

"There have been a lot of Reds lurking near the entrances and exits of our quarters," Meidani said. "I suspect all of the Ajahs are watching one another like that. It will be very difficult to get away without being noticed. They wouldn't follow me alone, but if they see you . . ."

spaɪz, wɑtʃɪŋ ði ʌðɝ ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝz? laɪt! hæɾ ɪt ɡɑɾən soʊ bæd? ðət wɑz laɪk skaʊts biɪŋ sɛn tə wɑtʃ ɛnəmi kæmps. ʃi kʊdn ɹɪsk biɪŋ sin livɪŋ wɪð maɪdɑni, bʌt tə ɡoʊ əloʊn wəd dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən, tu - ðə ɹɛdz nu ɛɡwin wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɡɑɹɾəd.

Spies, watching the other Ajah quarters? Light! Had it gotten so bad? That was like scouts being sent to watch enemy camps. She couldn't risk being seen leaving with Meidani, but to go alone would draw attention, too - the Reds knew Egwene was supposed to be guarded.

ðət lɛft ə pɹɑbləm, wʌn ɛɡwin kəd θɪŋk ʌv oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə sɑlv. ʃi aɪd maɪdɑni. haʊ fɑɹ tə tʃɹʌs hɝ? "ju pɹɑməs ðət jə də nɑt səpɔɹɾ ɪleɪɾə, ən ðət jə æksɛp maɪ liɾɝʃɪp?"

That left a problem, one Egwene could think of only one way to solve. She eyed Meidani. How far to trust her? "You promise that you do not support Elaida, and that you accept my leadership?"

ðə wʊmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd. "aɪ du."

The woman hesitated, then nodded. "I do."

"ɪf aɪ ʃoʊ jə sʌmθɪŋ, dʒju vaʊ nɑt tə ɹɪvil ɪt tə ɛniwʌn ɛls wɪθaʊt maɪ pɝmɪʃən fɝst?"

"If I show you something, do you vow not to reveal it to anyone else without my permission first?"

ʃi fɹaʊnd. "jɛs."

She frowned. "Yes."

ɛɡwin meɪɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒən. teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃi ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. "wɑtʃ kloʊsli," ʃi sɛd, wivɪŋ θɹɛdz ə spɪɹət. dæmpən baɪ fɔkɹut, ʃi wɑzn stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ, bʌt ʃi kəd stɪl ʃoʊ maɪdɑni ðə wivz.

Egwene made her decision. Taking a deep breath, she embraced the Source. "Watch closely," she said, weaving threads of Spirit. Dampened by forkroot, she wasn't strong enough to open a gateway, but she could still show Meidani the weaves.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðæt?" maɪdɑni æskt.

"What is that?" Meidani asked.

"ɪts kɔld ə ɡeɪtweɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "juz fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ."

"It's called a gateway," Egwene said. "Used for Traveling."

"tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪz ɪmpɑsəbəl!" maɪdɑni sɛɾ ɪmiɾiətli. "ði əbɪləɾi hæz bɪn lɔs fəɹ . . ." ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, aɪz oʊpənɪŋ mɔɹ waɪdli.

"Traveling is impossible!" Meidani said immediately. "The ability has been lost for . . ." She trailed off, eyes opening more widely.

ɛɡwin lɛt ðə wiv dɪsəpeɪt. ɪmiɾiətli, maɪdɑni ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, lʊkɪŋ dɪtɝmənd.

Egwene let the weave dissipate. Immediately, Meidani embraced the Source, looking determined.

"θɪŋk ə ðə pleɪs jə wɑnə ɡoʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ju hæv tə noʊ ðə pleɪs jəɹ livɪŋ bɪhaɪn vɛɹi wɛl tə meɪk ðɪs wɝk. aɪ əsum ðət jə ɑɹ fəmɪljɝ ɪnʌf wɪð jəɹ oʊn kɔɹɾɝz.

"Think of the place you want to go," Egwene said. "You have to know the place you're leaving behind very well to make this work. I assume that you are familiar enough with your own quarters.

pɪk ə dɛstəneɪʃən wɛɹ noʊbɑdi ɪz laɪkli tə bi; ɡeɪtweɪz kən bi deɪnʒɝəs ɪf ðeɪ oʊpən ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ loʊkeɪʃən."

Pick a destination where nobody is likely to be; gateways can be dangerous if they open in the wrong location."

maɪdɑni nɑɾəd, ɡoʊldən bʌn bɑbɪŋ əz ʃi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd. ʃi dɪɾ ən ædmɝəbəl dʒɑb ʌv ɪməteɪɾɪŋ ɛɡwinz wiv, ən ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən dɝɛkli bɪtwin ðə tu ʌv ðɛm, waɪt laɪn splɪɾɪŋ ði ɛɹ ən bɛndɪŋ əpɑn ɪtsɛlf. ðə hoʊl wɑz ɑn maɪdɑniz saɪd; ɛɡwin sɔ oʊnli ə ʃɪmɝɪŋ pætʃ, laɪk ə dʒɹæft ə hit wɔɹpɪŋ ði ɛɹ. ʃi ɹaʊndəd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, lʊkɪŋ θɹu ðə hoʊl əɾ ə dɑɹkən stoʊn hɔlweɪ bɪɑnd. ðə taɪlz ɑn ðə flɔɹ wɝ ʌv ə səbdud waɪɾ ən bɹaʊn, ən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wɪndoʊz wɪðɪn saɪt. ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə ðə taʊɝ, ɛɡwin ɡɛst.

Meidani nodded, golden bun bobbing as she concentrated. She did an admirable job of imitating Egwene's weave, and a gateway opened directly between the two of them, white line splitting the air and bending upon itself. The hole was on Meidani's side; Egwene saw only a shimmering patch, like a draft of heat warping the air. She rounded the gateway, looking through the hole at a darkened stone hallway beyond. The tiles on the floor were of a subdued white and brown, and there were no windows within sight. In the depths of the Tower, Egwene guessed.

"kwɪkli," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪf aɪ doʊn ɹɪtɝn fɹəm jəɹ kɔɹɾɝz æftɝ əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝ, maɪ ɹɛd maɪndɝz maɪt bɪɡɪn tə wʌndɝ wʌɾ ɪz teɪkɪŋ soʊ lɔŋ. ɪts ɔlɹɛɾi səspɪʃəs tə hæv ju, ʌv ɔl pipəl, sɛn fəɹ mi. wi kən oʊnli hoʊp ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə ɪzən kɛɹfəl ɪnʌf tə wʌndɝ ət ðə koʊɪnsɪɾəns."

"Quickly," Egwene said. "If I don't return from your quarters after about an hour, my Red minders might begin to wonder what is taking so long. It's already suspicious to have you, of all people, send for me. We can only hope that Elaida isn't careful enough to wonder at the coincidence."

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," maɪdɑni sɛd, ɹʌʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ən teɪkɪŋ ə bɹɑnz læmp fɹəm əɹ teɪbəl, ðə fleɪm flɪkɝɪŋ ət ðə spaʊt. ðən ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

"Yes, Mother," Meidani said, rushing over and taking a bronze lamp from her table, the flame flickering at the spout. Then she hesitated.

"wʌt?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"What?" Egwene asked.

"aɪm dʒʌst sɝpɹaɪzd."

"I'm just surprised."

ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊst æskt wʌt wɑz soʊ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ, bʌt ðən ʃi sɔ ɪɾ ɪn maɪdɑniz aɪz. maɪdɑni wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ kwɪkli ʃid faʊn hɝsɛlf oʊbeɪɪŋ. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz baɪ haʊ nætʃɹəl ɪt wɑz tə θɪŋk ʌv ɛɡwin əz æmɪɝlɪn. ðɪs wʊmən hædn bɪn wʌn oʊvɝ kəmplitli, nɑt jɛt, bʌt ʃi wɑz kloʊs.

Egwene almost asked what was so surprising, but then she saw it in Meidani's eyes. Meidani was surprised at how quickly she'd found herself obeying. She was surprised by how natural it was to think of Egwene as Amyrlin. This woman hadn't been won over completely, not yet, but she was close.

"kwɪkli," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Quickly," Egwene said.

maɪdɑni nɑɾəd, stɛpɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən ɛɡwin fɑloʊd. ðoʊ ðə flɔɹ bɪɑnd wɑz fɹi ʌv dʌst, ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɑz θɪk wɪð ðə mʌsti sɛn ʌv ʌnsɝkjəleɪɾɪd ɛɹ. ðə wɔlz wɝ bɛɹ ə ði ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃənz wʌn sɔ əkeɪʒənəli ɪn ði ʌpɝ kɔɹɪɾɝz, ən ði oʊnli saʊnd wɑz ðəɾ ʌv ə fju dɪstən ɹæts skɹætʃɪŋ. ɹæts. ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. wʌns, ðət wʊɾə bɪn ɪmpɑsəbəl. ðə feɪljɝ ə ðə wɔɹdz wɑz dʒʌst wʌn mɔɹ ɪmpɔsɪbɪlɪɾi ətɑp ən ɛvɝ-ɡɹoʊɪŋ stæk.

Meidani nodded, stepping through the gateway, and Egwene followed. Though the floor beyond was free of dust, the corridor was thick with the musty scent of uncirculated air. The walls were bare of the ornamentations one saw occasionally in the upper corridors, and the only sound was that of a few distant rats scratching. Rats. In the White Tower. Once, that would have been impossible. The failure of the wards was just one more impossibility atop an ever-growing stack.

ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ən ɛɹiə ɔfən ɡɪvən ətɛnʃən baɪ ðə taʊɝ sɝvəns. ðət wɑz pɹɑbli waɪ maɪdɑni hæd tʃoʊzən ɪt tə oʊpən ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðət wɑz wɛl ən ɡʊd, bʌt ʃi wɑz pɹɑbli ɛɹɪŋ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə seɪfti. ðɪs dip wɪðɪn ðə taʊɝ, ɪt wəd teɪk pɹɛʃəs mɪnəts tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə meɪn hɔlweɪz ən faɪnd wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz maɪdɑni wɪʃt tə ʃoʊ hɝ. ən ðət wəd pɹizɛn ɪts oʊn pɹɑbləmz. wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf ʌðɝ sɪstɝz tʊk noʊɾ ʌv ɛɡwin muvɪŋ θɹu ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz wɪθaʊɾ əɹ nɔɹməl kɑmpləmən ə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɡɑɹdz?

This was not an area often given attention by the Tower servants. That was probably why Meidani had chosen it to open the gateway. That was well and good, but she was probably erring on the side of safety. This deep within the Tower, it would take precious minutes to return to the main hallways and find whatever it was Meidani wished to show her. And that would present its own problems. What would happen if other sisters took note of Egwene moving through the corridors without her normal complement of Red Ajah guards?

bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin kəd vɔɪs ðɪs kənsɝn, maɪdɑni bɪɡæn tə wɔk əweɪ. nɑɾ ʌp ðə hɔlweɪ təwɔɹd ðə stɛɹwəlz, bʌt daʊn ɪt, muvɪŋ dipɝ. ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd, bʌt fɑloʊd.

Before Egwene could voice this concern, Meidani began to walk away. Not up the hallway toward the stairwells, but down it, moving deeper. Egwene frowned, but followed.

"aɪm nɑt sɝɾən ɪf əl bi əlaʊd tə ʃoʊ ju," maɪdɑni sɛd sɔfli, hɝ skɝts swɪʃɪŋ, ðə saʊnd nɑɾ ənlaɪk ðəɾ ə ðə feɪn skɹæmbəlɪŋ ə ðə dɪstən ɹæts. "aɪ mʌst wɔɹn ju, haʊɛvɝ, ðət jə meɪ bi sɝpɹaɪzd ət wʌt jə ɑɹ stɛpɪŋ ɪntu. ɪt kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs."

"I'm not certain if I'll be allowed to show you," Meidani said softly, her skirts swishing, the sound not unlike that of the faint scrambling of the distant rats. "I must warn you, however, that you may be surprised at what you are stepping into. It could be dangerous."

dɪd maɪdɑni min fɪzɪkəl deɪnʒɝ əɹ pəlɪɾəkəl deɪnʒɝ? ɪt sim ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ɪn əbaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ ə ðə læɾɝ əz wɑz pɑsəbəl. stɪl, ʃi nɑɾəd ən æksɛptɪd ðə wɔɹnɪŋ wɪð səlɛmnəɾi. "aɪ ʌndɝstænd. bʌɾ ɪf sʌmθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs ɪz hæpənɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, aɪ mʌs noʊ ʌv ɪt. ɪts nɑɾ oʊnli maɪ ɹaɪt, bʌt maɪ duɾi."

Did Meidani mean physical danger or political danger? It seemed that Egwene was in about as much of the latter as was possible. Still, she nodded and accepted the warning with solemnity. "I understand. But if something dangerous is happening in the Tower, I must know of it. It is not only my right, but my duty."

maɪdɑni sɛd noʊ mɔɹ. ʃi lɛɾ ɛɡwin θɹu ðə twɪstɪŋ pæsədʒ, mʌɾɝɪŋ ðət ʃiɾ əv laɪk tə hæv bɪn eɪbəl tə bɹɪŋ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ. hi wɑz əpɛɹənli aʊɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɑn səm ɛɹənd. ðə hɔl spaɪɹəl nɑɾ ənlaɪk ði ʌnʒəleɪtɪŋ kɔɪlz ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɪtsɛlf. dʒʌst wən ɛɡwin wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənt, maɪdɑni stɑp bɪsaɪɾ ə kloʊz dɔɹ. ɪt lʊk noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə dʌzənz ʌv ʌðɝ nɪɹ-fɝɡɑɾən stɔɹədʒ ɹumz ðət bʌddɪɾ ɔf ðə meɪn kɔɹəɾɝ. maɪdɑni ɹeɪzd ə hɛzɪɾənt hænd, ðən nɑkt ʃɑɹpli.

Meidani said no more. She led Egwene through the twisting passage, muttering that she'd have liked to have been able to bring her Warder. He was apparently out in the city on some errand. The hall spiraled not unlike the undulating coils of the Great Serpent itself. Just when Egwene was growing impatient, Meidani stopped beside a closed door. It looked no different from the dozens of other near-forgotten storage rooms that budded off the main corridor. Meidani raised a hesitant hand, then knocked sharply.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ɪmiɾiətli, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə kin-aɪd wɔɹɾɝ wɪð ɹʌɾi hɛɹ ən ə skwɛɹ dʒɔ.

The door opened immediately, revealing a keen-eyed Warder with ruddy hair and a square jaw.

hi aɪd maɪdɑni, ðən tɝn tə ɛɡwin, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹkɝ. hɪz ɑɹm flɪntʃt, əz ɪf hid dʒʌs bɛɹli stɑp hɪmsɛlf fɹəm ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd.

He eyed Meidani, then turned to Egwene, his expression growing darker. His arm flinched, as if he'd just barely stopped himself from reaching for the sword at his side.

"ðæt wɪl bi maɪdɑni," ə wʊmənz vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum, "kʌm tə ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn əɹ miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡɝl. ədsɔlən?"

"That will be Meidani," a woman's voice said from inside the room, "come to report on her meeting with the girl. Adsalan?"

ðə wɔɹɾɝ stɛpt əsaɪd, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə smɔl tʃeɪmbɝ sɛt wɪð bɑksəz fəɹ tʃɛɹz. ɪt hɛl fɔɹ wɪmən, ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ. ænd, ʃɑkɪŋli, itʃ wɑz ʌv ə dɪfɹən ədʒɑ! ɛɡwin hædn sin wɪmən ə fɔɹ dɪfɹən ədʒəz soʊ mʌtʃ əz wɔk təɡɛðɝ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz, lɛɾ əloʊn hoʊl kɑnfɝəns təɡɛðɝ. nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz ɹɛd, ən itʃ ə ðə fɔɹ wɑz ə sɪɾɝ.

The Warder stepped aside, revealing a small chamber set with boxes for chairs. It held four women, all Aes Sedai. And, shockingly, each was of a different Ajah! Egwene hadn't seen women of four different Ajahs so much as walk together in the hallways, let alone hold conference together. Not a single one of them was Red, and each of the four was a Sitter.

sin wɑz ðə steɪtli wʊmən ɪn waɪt ɹoʊbz ən sɪlvɝ tʃɹɪm. eɪ sɪɾɝ fɹəm ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ, ʃi hæd θɪk blæk hɛɹ ən aɪbɹaʊz, ən wɔɾɝi blu aɪz ðət ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɛɡwin wɪð ən ivən ɪkspɹɛʃən. bɪsaɪɾ əɹ wɑz dʌsin, ə sɪɾɝ ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ. ʃi wɑz slɛndɝ ən tɔl fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn; hɝ ɹɪtʃ ɹoʊz-kʌlɝd dʒɹɛs wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɡoʊld. hɝ hɛɹ wɑz ədɔɹnd wɪð sæfaɪɝz, mætʃt baɪ ðə stoʊn əɾ əɹ fɔɹhɛd.

Seaine was the stately woman in white robes and silver trim. A Sitter from the White Ajah, she had thick black hair and eyebrows, and watery blue eyes that regarded Egwene with an even expression. Beside her was Doesine, a Sitter of the Yellow Ajah. She was slender and tall for a Cairhienin; her rich rose-colored dress was embroidered with gold. Her hair was adorned with sapphires, matched by the stone at her forehead.

jukɪɝi wɑz ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ sɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd dʌsin. jukɪɝi wɑz wʌn ə ðə ʃɔɹɾɪst wɪmən ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛt, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ʌðɝz ðəɾ ɔlweɪz meɪɾ əɹ sim ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl, ivən wən əkʌmpənid baɪ vɛɹi tɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə læst wʊmən wɑz sɹɪn, ən ɔltɑɹən sɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə bɹaʊn. laɪk mɛni bɹaʊnz, ʃi wɔɹ ənɔɹnəmɛntɪd dʒɹɛsəz, ðɪs wʌn ə nɑndɪskɹɪp tæn. hɝ ɑləv skɪn wɑz mɑɹd baɪ ə skɑɹ ɑn əɹ lɛf tʃik. ɛɡwin nu vɛɹi lɪɾəl əbaʊt hɝ. ʌv ɔl ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə ɹum, ʃi sim ðə list ʃɑk tə si ɛɡwin.

Yukiri was the Gray sister sitting beside Doesine. Yukiri was one of the shortest women that Egwene had ever met, but she had a way of regarding others that always made her seem in control, even when accompanied by very tall Aes Sedai. The last woman was Saerin, an Altaran Sitter for the Brown. Like many Browns, she wore unornamented dresses, this one a nondescript tan. Her olive skin was marred by a scar on her left cheek. Egwene knew very little about her. Of all the sisters in the room, she seemed the least shocked to see Egwene.

"wʌɾ əv jə dʌn?" sin sɛd tə maɪdɑni, əɡæst.

"What have you done?" Seaine said to Meidani, aghast.

"ədsɔlən, bɹɪŋ əm ɪn hɪɹ," dʌsin sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ ən dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ɝdʒənli. "ɪf sʌmwʌn wɝ tə wɔk baɪ ən si ði ælvɪɹ ɡɝl ðɛɹ. . . ."

"Adsalan, bring them in here," Doesine said, rising and gesturing urgently. "If someone were to walk by and see the al'Vere girl there. . . ."

maɪdɑni kɹɪnʒd bɪfɔɹ ðə stɝn wɝdz - jɛs, ʃi wəd ɹikwaɪɝ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv wɝk bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd ðə bɛɹɪŋ ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɛn. ɛɡwin stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum, muvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹuɾɪʃ wɔɹɾɝ kəd pʊl əɹ fɔɹwɝd. maɪdɑni fɑloʊd, ən ədsɔlən kloʊz ðə dɔɹ wɪð ə θʌmp. ðə ɹum wɑz lɪt baɪ ə pɛɹ ə læmps ðət dɪdnt ɡɪv kwaɪɾ ɪnʌf laɪt, əz ɪf tə kɑmpləmən ðə kənspɪɹətɔɹiəl neɪtʃɝ ə ðə wɪmənz kɑnfɝəns.

Meidani cringed before the stern words - yes, she would require a great deal of work before she had the bearing of an Aes Sedai again. Egwene stepped into the room, moving before the brutish Warder could pull her forward. Meidani followed, and Adsalan closed the door with a thump. The room was lit by a pair of lamps that didn't give quite enough light, as if to complement the conspiratorial nature of the women's conference.

ðə bɑksəz maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn θɹoʊnz fəɹ ðə weɪ ðə fɔɹ sɪɾɝz ɑkjəpaɪd ðɛm, ən soʊ ɛɡwin sæt hɝsɛlf ɑn wʌn əz wɛl. "ju wɝ nɑt ɡɪvən liv tə sɪt, ɡɝl," sɹɪn sɛd koʊldli.

The boxes might as well have been thrones for the way the four Sitters occupied them, and so Egwene sat herself on one as well. "You were not given leave to sit, girl," Saerin said coldly.

"maɪdɑni, wʌɾ ɪz ðə minɪŋ ə ðɪs aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ? jəɹ oʊθ wɑz tə hæv pɹɪvɛntɪd ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə læps!"

"Meidani, what is the meaning of this outrage? Your oath was to have prevented this sort of lapse!"

"oʊθ?" ɛɡwin æskt. "ænd wɪtʃ oʊθ wəd ðɪs bi?"

"Oath?" Egwene asked. "And which oath would this be?"

"kwaɪət, ɡɝl," jukɪɝi snæpt, slæpɪŋ ɛɡwin əkɹɔs ðə bæk wɪð ə swɪtʃ ʌv ɛɹ. ɪt wɑz sətʃ ə feɪn pʌnɪʃmən ðəɾ ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊs læft.

"Quiet, girl," Yukiri snapped, slapping Egwene across the back with a switch of Air. It was such a faint punishment that Egwene almost laughed.

"aɪ dɪdn bɹeɪk maɪ oʊθ!" maɪdɑni sɛd kwɪkli, stɛpɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɛɡwin. "ju ɔɹɾɝd mi nɑt tə tɛl ɛniwʌn ə ðiz miɾɪŋz. wɛl, aɪ hæv oʊbeɪd - aɪ dɪdn tɛl hɝ. aɪ ʃoʊd hɝ." ðəɹ wɑz ə spɑɹk ə dɪfaɪəns ɪn ðə wʊmən. ðət wɑz ɡʊd.

"I didn't break my oath!" Meidani said quickly, stepping up beside Egwene. "You ordered me not to tell anyone of these meetings. Well, I have obeyed - I didn't tell her. I showed her." There was a spark of defiance in the woman. That was good.

ɛɡwin wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə ɹum, bʌt fɔɹ sɪɾɝz təɡɛðɝ pɹizɛntəɾ əɹ wɪð ən ənikwʌld ɑpɝtunəɾi. ʃid nɛvɝ θɔt tə ɡɛɾ ə tʃæns tə spik wɪð soʊ mɛni ət wʌns, ən ɪf ðiz wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə mit təɡɛðɝ, ðən pɝhæps ðeɪ wɝ fɹi ʌv ðə fɹæktʃɝz ʌndɝmaɪnɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taʊɝ.

Egwene wasn't certain what was going on in the room, but four Sitters together presented her with an unequaled opportunity. She'd never thought to get a chance to speak with so many at once, and if these were willing to meet together, then perhaps they were free of the fractures undermining the rest of the Tower.

əɹ wɑz ðɛɹ miɾɪŋ ə hɪn ə sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ dɑɹk? oʊðz ɛɡwin dɪdnt noʊ əbaʊt, miɾɪŋz əweɪ fɹəm ði ʌpɝ kɔɹɪɾɝz, ə wɔɹɾɝ ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə dɔɹ . . . wɝ ðiz wɪmən ə fɔɹ ədʒəz, əɹ ʌv wʌn? hæd ʃi ənwɪɾɪŋli bʌmbəld əɹ weɪ ɪndə ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ə nɛst ə blæks?

Or was their meeting a hint of something more dark? Oaths Egwene didn't know about, meetings away from the upper corridors, a Warder guarding the door . . . were these women of four Ajahs, or of one? Had she unwittingly bumbled her way into the center of a nest of Blacks?

hɑɹt bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹeɪs, ɛɡwin fɔɹs hɝsɛlf nɑt tə dʒʌmp tə kənkluʒənz. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ blæk, ðən ʃi wɑz kɑt. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt, ðən ʃi hæd wɝk tə du.

Heart beginning to race, Egwene forced herself not to jump to conclusions. If they were Black, then she was caught. If they were not, then she had work to do.

"ðɪs ɪz vɛɹi ʌnɪkspɛktɪd," kɑm sin wɑz seɪɪŋ tə maɪdɑni. "wil teɪk ɛkstʃɹə kɛɹ wɪð ðə wɝɾɪŋ ə jəɹ fjutʃɝ ɔɹɾɝz, maɪdɑni."

"This is very unexpected," calm Seaine was saying to Meidani. "We'll take extra care with the wording of your future orders, Meidani."

jukɪɝi nɑɾəd. "aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk ðət jud bi soʊ tʃaɪldɪʃ əz tə ɪkspoʊz əs aʊɾ ə spaɪt. wi ʃʊɾə ɹilaɪz ðət ju, laɪk ɔl ʌv ʌs, wəɾ əv ɪkspɪɹiəns pʊʃɪŋ ən bɛndɪŋ oʊðz tə sut jəɹ nidz."

Yukiri nodded. "I didn't think that you'd be so childish as to expose us out of spite. We should have realized that you, like all of us, would have experience pushing and bending oaths to suit your needs."

weɪt, ɛɡwin θɔt. ðət saʊnz laɪk. . . .

Wait, Egwene thought. That sounds like. . . .

"ɪndid," jukɪɝi sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ðət pɛnəns wɪl bi ɪn ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ ðɪs ɪnfɹækʃən. bʌt wʌɾ ɑɹ wi tə də wɪð ðɪs ɡɝl ʃi bɹɔt? ʃiz nɑt swɔɹn ɑn ðə ɹɑd, ən soʊ ɪt wəd bi - "

"Indeed," Yukiri said. "I think that penance will be in order for this infraction. But what are we to do with this girl she brought? She's not sworn on the Rod, and so it would be - "

"ju ɡeɪv əɹ ə fɔɹθ oʊθ, dɪdn ju?" ɛɡwin ɪntɝʌptɪd. "wʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt wɝ jə θɪŋkɪŋ?"

"You gave her a fourth oath, didn't you?" Egwene interrupted. "What under the Light were you thinking?"

jukɪɝi ɡlænst ət hɝ, ən ɛɡwin fɛlt ənʌðɝ swɪʃ ʌv ɛɹ. "ju wɝ nɑt ɡɪvən liv tə spik."

Yukiri glanced at her, and Egwene felt another swish of Air. "You were not given leave to speak."

"ði æmɪɝlɪn nidz noʊ liv tə spik," ɛɡwin sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ðə wɪmən daʊn. "wʌɾ əv jə dʌn hɪɹ, jukɪɝi? jə bɪtʃɹeɪ ɔl ðət wi ɑɹ! ði oʊðz ɑɹ nɑt tə bi juzd əz tulz ə dɪvɪʒən. hæz ðɪs ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ ɡɔn əz ɪnseɪn əz ɪleɪɾə?"

"The Amyrlin needs no leave to speak," Egwene said, staring the women down. "What have you done here, Yukiri? You betray all that we are! The Oaths are not to be used as tools of division. Has this entire Tower gone as insane as Elaida?"

"ɪts nɑɾ ɪnsænəɾi," sɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli, bʌɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən. ðə bɹaʊn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, mɔɹ kəmændɪŋ ðən ɛɡwin wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd fəɹ wʌn ə hɝ ədʒɑ. "ɪt wɑz oʊnli dʌn aʊɾ ə nəsɛsəɾi. ðɪs wʌn kʊdn bi tʃɹʌstɪd, nɑɾ æftɝ saɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz."

"It's not insanity," Saerin said suddenly, butting into the conversation. The Brown shook her head, more commanding than Egwene would have expected for one of her Ajah. "It was only done out of necessity. This one couldn't be trusted, not after siding with the rebels."

"du nɑt θɪŋk wɝ ʌnəwɛɹ ə jəɹ oʊn ɪnvɑlvmənt wɪð ðət ɡɹup, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," jukɪɝi sɛd. ðə hɔɾi ɡɹeɪ wɑz bɛɹli ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝ æŋɡɝ. "ɪf wɪv əɹ weɪ, jəl nɑt bi tʃɹiɾəd wɪð sətʃ kɑɾəlɪŋ əz ɪleɪɾə hæz ʃoʊn ju."

"Do not think we're unaware of your own involvement with that group, Egwene al'Vere," Yukiri said. The haughty Gray was barely in control of her anger. "If we have our way, you will not be treated with such coddling as Elaida has shown you."

ɛɡwin dʒɛstʃɝɾ ɪndɪfɹənli. "stɪl mi, ɛksəkjut mi əɹ bit mi, jukɪɝi, ən ðə taʊɝ wɪl jɛt bi ɪn ʃæmbəlz. ðə wʌnz jə soʊ izəli leɪbəl əz ɹɛbəlz ɑɹ nɑt tə bleɪm fəɹ ðæt. sikɹət miɾɪŋz ɪn ðə beɪsməns, oʊðz ədmɪnəstɝd wɪθaʊt wɔɹənt - ðiz ɑɹ kɹaɪmz ət list ikwəl tə ðəɾ ə dɪvaɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪleɪɾə."

Egwene gestured indifferently. "Still me, execute me or beat me, Yukiri, and the Tower will yet be in shambles. The ones you so easily label as rebels are not to blame for that. Secret meetings in the basements, oaths administered without warrant - these are crimes at least equal to that of dividing from Elaida."

"ju ʃəd nɑt kwɛstʃən ʌs," sin sɛɾ ɪn ə kwaɪəɾɝ vɔɪs. ʃi simd mɔɹ tɪmɪd ðən ði ʌðɝz. "səmtaɪmz, dɪfəkəl dɪsɪʒənz mʌs bi meɪd. wi kænɑɾ əv dɑɹkfɹɛnz əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən mɛʒɝz əv bɪn teɪkən tə sɝtʃ əm aʊt. wi hɪɹ itʃ pɹuv tə maɪdɑni ðət wəɹ nɑt fɹɛnz ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ən soʊ ðəɹ kən bi noʊ hɑɹm ɪn meɪkɪŋ əɹ ɡɪv ən oʊθ tə ʌs. ɪt wɑz ə ɹizənəbəl ækʃən tə meɪk sɝɾən wəɹ ɔl wɝkɪŋ fəɹ ðə seɪm ɡoʊlz."

"You should not question us," Seaine said in a quieter voice. She seemed more timid than the others. "Sometimes, difficult decisions must be made. We cannot have Darkfriends among the Aes Sedai, and measures have been taken to search them out. We here each proved to Meidani that we are not friends of the Shadow, and so there can be no harm in making her give an oath to us. It was a reasonable action to make certain we are all working for the same goals."

ɛɡwin kɛpt əɹ feɪs kɑm. sin hæɾ ɔl bʌɾ ədmɪɾəd tə ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ!

Egwene kept her face calm. Seaine had all but admitted to the existence of the Black Ajah!

ɛɡwin hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə hɪɹ ðət fɹəm ðə maʊθ ʌv ə sɪɾɝ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪn fɹʌn ə soʊ mɛni wɪtnəsəz. soʊ ðiz wɪmən wɝ juzɪŋ ði oʊθ ɹɑd tə sɝtʃ aʊt blæk sɪstɝz. ɪf jə tʊk itʃ sɪstɝ, ɹimuvd əɹ oʊðz ən meɪɾ əɹ ɹɛswɛɹ ðɛm, jə kəɾ æsk əɹ ɪf ʃi wɝ blæk. ə dɛspɹɪt mɛθəd, bʌt - ɛɡwin dɪsaɪɾɪd - ə lədʒɪɾəmət wʌn, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə taɪmz.

Egwene had never expected to hear that from the mouth of a Sitter, particularly in front of so many witnesses. So these women were using the Oath Rod to search out Black sisters. If you took each sister, removed her oaths and made her reswear them, you could ask her if she were Black. A desperate method, but - Egwene decided - a legitimate one, considering the times.

"aɪ kənsid ðəɾ ɪts ə ɹizənəbəl plæn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌt swɛɹɪŋ ðɪs wʊmən tə ə nu oʊθ ɪz ənnɛsəsɛɹi!"

"I concede that it is a reasonable plan," Egwene said. "But swearing this woman to a new oath is unnecessary!"

"æn ɪf ðə wʊmən ɪz noʊn tə hæv ʌðɝ lɔɪəltiz?" sɹɪn dɪmændəd. "dʒʌs kəz ə wʊmən ɪzən ə dɑɹkfɹɛn dʌzn min ʃi woʊn bɪtʃɹeɪ əs ɪn ʌðɝ weɪz."

"And if the woman is known to have other loyalties?" Saerin demanded. "Just because a woman isn't a Darkfriend doesn't mean she won't betray us in other ways."

ən ðəɾ oʊθ ʌv oʊbiɾiəns wɑz pɹɑbli ðə ɹizən maɪdɑni kʊdn fli ðə taʊɝ. ɛɡwin fɛlt ə stæb ə sɪmpəθi fəɹ ðə pʊɹ wʊmən. sɛn baɪ ðə sɑlədɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ɹɪtɝn ən spaɪ ɑn ðə taʊɝ, dɪskʌvɝd baɪ ðiz wɪmən - pɹəzuməbli - dʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ sɝtʃ fəɹ ðə blæk, ðən ɹɪvild ɪn əɹ tʃɹu pɝpəs tə ɪleɪɾə. θɹi dɪfɹən fækʃənz, ɔl pʊʃɪŋ əɡɛns hɝ.

And that oath of obedience was probably the reason Meidani couldn't flee the Tower. Egwene felt a stab of sympathy for the poor woman. Sent by the Salidar Aes Sedai to return and spy on the Tower, discovered by these women - presumably - during their search for the Black, then revealed in her true purpose to Elaida. Three different factions, all pushing against her.

sɹɪn lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd, bʌt kjʊɹiəs. jukɪɝi, stɪl stændɪŋ wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz foʊldəd, wɑz nɑt soʊ izəli dɪsweɪɾɪd. "ðæts minɪŋləs. wɪl dʒʌst ɔɹɾɝ əɹ tə sɛn jə tə pɛnəns."

naʊ tɛl mi ðɪs. wɝ ɛni ʌv ðiz blæk sɪɾɝz əmʌŋ ðoʊz u ɹeɪzd ɪleɪɾə? dɪɾ ɛni ʌv əm stæn tə dɪpoʊz sɪuən?"

ɛɡwin tɝn təwɔɹd hɝ, ɡlæd ðeɪ kʊdn hɪɹ əɹ nɝvəsli paʊndɪŋ hɑɹt. ʃi hæd tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. ʃi hæd tə. "ju kɔl əs fɔls, jukɪɝi? wɪtʃ æmɪɝlɪn wəd jə ɹæðɝ fɑloʊ?

Egwene turned toward her, glad they couldn't hear her nervously pounding heart. She had to remain in control. She had to. "You call us false, Yukiri? Which Amyrlin would you rather follow?

ðə wʌn u hæz bɪn meɪkɪŋ nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, bænɪʃɪŋ ən ɪntaɪɝ ədʒɑ, ən kɑzɪŋ dɪvɪʒənz ɪn ðə taʊɝ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən ɛni ɑɹmi ðəɾ ɛvɝ əsɔltɪɾ ɪt? ə wʊmən u wɑz ɹeɪz pɑɹʃəli θɹu ðə hɛlp ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ? əɹ wəd jə ɹæðɝ sɝv ði æmɪɝlɪn u ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əndu ɔl ə ðæt?"

The one who has been making novices and Accepted out of Aes Sedai, banishing an entire Ajah, and causing divisions in the Tower more dangerous than any army that ever assaulted it? A woman who was raised partially through the help of the Black Ajah? Or would you rather serve the Amyrlin who is trying to undo all of that?"

"ʃʊɹli jəɹ nɑt seɪɪŋ ðət jə θɪŋk wi sɝv ðə blæk ɪn ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪleɪɾə," dʌsin sɛd.

"Surely you're not saying that you think we served the Black in raising Elaida," Doesine said.

"aɪ θɪŋk wi ɔl ɑɹ sɝvɪŋ ði ɪntʃɹəsts ə ðə ʃædoʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd ʃɑɹpli, "soʊ lɔŋ əz wi əlaʊ aʊɝsɛlvz tə ɹɪmeɪn dɪvaɪɾəd. haʊ dʒju ɪmædʒən ðə blæk ɹiæktəd tə ðə nɪɹ-sikɹət dəpoʊzɪŋ ʌv ən æmɪɝlɪn sit, fɑloʊd baɪ ə dɪvɪʒən əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ? aɪ wəd nɑt bi sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪnd, æftɝ səm ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən, ðət ðɪs neɪmləs blæk sɪstɝ jə dɪskʌvɝd wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli dɑɹkfɹɛn əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹup u wɝk tə ənsit ðə ɹaɪtfəl æmɪɝlɪn."

"I think we all are serving the interests of the Shadow," Egwene said sharply, "so long as we allow ourselves to remain divided. How do you imagine the Black reacted to the near-secret deposing of an Amyrlin Seat, followed by a division among the Aes Sedai? I would not be surprised to find, after some investigation, that this nameless Black sister you discovered was not the only Darkfriend among the group who worked to unseat the rightful Amyrlin."

ðɪs bɹɔɾ ənʌðɝ ɹaʊn ə saɪləns tə ðə ɹum.

This brought another round of silence to the room.

sɹɪn sɛɾəld bæk ən saɪd. "wi kænɑt tʃeɪnʒ ðə pæst. ɛnlaɪɾənɪŋ ðoʊ jəɹ ɑɹɡjəməns ɑɹ, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ʌltəmətli fɹutləs."

Saerin settled back and sighed. "We cannot change the past. Enlightening though your arguments are, Egwene al'Vere, they are ultimately fruitless."

"aɪ əɡɹi ðət wi kænɑt tʃeɪnʒ wʌɾ əz hæpənd," ɛɡwin sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə hɝ. "haʊɛvɝ, wi kən lʊk tə ðə fjutʃɝ. əz ædmɝəbəl əz aɪ faɪn jəɹ wɝk tə dɪskʌvɝ ðə blæk ədʒɑ, aɪm fɑɹ mɔɹ ɛnkɝɪdʒ baɪ jəɹ wɪlɪŋnəs tə wɝk təɡɛðɝ tə də ɪt. ɪn ðə kɝən taʊɝ, koʊɑpɝeɪʃən bɪtwin ði ədʒəz ɪz ɹɛɹ. aɪ tʃælənʒ jə tə teɪk ðəɾ əz jəɹ meɪn ɡoʊl, bɹɪŋɪŋ junəɾi tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

"I agree that we cannot change what has happened," Egwene said, nodding to her. "However, we can look to the future. As admirable as I find your work to discover the Black Ajah, I am far more encouraged by your willingness to work together to do it. In the current Tower, cooperation between the Ajahs is rare. I challenge you to take that as your main goal, bringing unity to the White Tower.

wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑst."

Whatever the cost."

ʃi stʊɾ ʌp, ən ʃi hæf-ɪkspɛktəɾ ə sɪstɝ tə ɹibjuk hɝ, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlmoʊst sim tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən ðət ðeɪ wɝ spikɪŋ wɪð ə "nɑvəs" ən ə ɹɛbəl. "maɪdɑni," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ju æksɛp mi əz æmɪɝlɪn."

She stood up, and she half-expected a sister to rebuke her, but they almost seemed to have forgotten that they were speaking with a "novice" and a rebel. "Meidani," Egwene said. "You accept me as Amyrlin."

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," ðə wʊmən sɛd, boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd.

"Yes, Mother," the woman said, bowing her head.

"aɪ tʃɑɹdʒ ju, ðɛn, tə kəntɪnju jəɹ wɝk wɪð ðiz wɪmən. ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ əɹ ɛnəmiz ən ðeɪ nɛvɝ wɝ. sɛndɪŋ jə bæk əz ə spaɪ wɑz ə mɪsteɪk, wʌn aɪ wɪʃ aɪd bɪn eɪbəl tə stɑp. naʊ ðət jə ɑɹ hɪɹ, haʊɛvɝ, jə kən bi ʌv jus. aɪ ɹəɡɹɛt ðət jə mʌs kəntɪnju jəɹ pɝfɔɹməns bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪɾə, bʌɾ aɪ kəmɛn jə fəɹ jəɹ kɝədʒ ɪn ðət ɹəɡɑɹd."

"I charge you, then, to continue your work with these women. They are not our enemies and they never were. Sending you back as a spy was a mistake, one I wish I'd been able to stop. Now that you are here, however, you can be of use. I regret that you must continue your performance before Elaida, but I commend you for your courage in that regard."

"aɪ wɪl sɝv əz niɾəd, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd, ðoʊ ʃi lʊk sɪk.

"I will serve as needed, Mother," she said, though she looked sick.

ɛɡwin ɡlænst ət ði ʌðɝz. "lɔɪəlti ɪz bɛɾɝ ɝn ðən fɔɹst. juv ði oʊθ ɹɑd hɪɹ?"

Egwene glanced at the others. "Loyalty is better earned than forced. Do you have the Oath Rod here?"

"noʊ," jukɪɝi sɛd. "ɪts dɪfəkəl tə snik əweɪ. wi kən oʊnli teɪk ɪɾ ɑn əkeɪʒən."

"No," Yukiri said. "It's difficult to sneak away. We can only take it on occasion."

"ə pɪɾi," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪɾ əv laɪk tə teɪk ði oʊðz. ɹəɡɑɹdləs, jəl pɹɑmpli teɪk ɪɾ ən ɹilis maɪdɑni fɹəm ðə fɔɹθ oʊθ."

"A pity," Egwene said. "I'd have liked to take the oaths. Regardless, you will promptly take it and release Meidani from the fourth oath."

"wil kənsɪɾɝ ɪt," sɹɪn sɛd.

"We'll consider it," Saerin said.

ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "æz jə wɪʃ. bʌt noʊ ðət wʌns ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz hoʊl əɡɛn, ðə hɔl wɪl lɝn ə ðɪs ækʃən juv teɪkən. aɪ wəd laɪk tə bi eɪbəl tə ɪnfɔɹm əm ðət jə wɝ biɪŋ kɛɹfəl, ɹæðɝ ðən sikɪŋ ənwɔɹəntɪd paʊɝ. ɪf jə nid mi ɪn ðə nɛks fju deɪz, jə meɪ sɛn fəɹ mi - bʌt kaɪnli faɪn ə weɪ tə dil wɪð ðə tu ɹɛd sɪstɝz u ɑɹ wɑtʃɪŋ mi. aɪd ɹæðɝ nɑt juz tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪðɪn ðə taʊɝ əɡɛn, lɛst aɪ ənwɪɾɪŋli ɹɪvil tu mʌtʃ tə ðoʊz u wəd bi bɛɾɝ lɛft ɪɡnɝənt."

Egwene raised an eyebrow. "As you wish. But know that once the White Tower is whole again, the Hall will learn of this action you have taken. I would like to be able to inform them that you were being careful, rather than seeking unwarranted power. If you need me in the next few days, you may send for me - but kindly find a way to deal with the two Red sisters who are watching me. I'd rather not use Traveling within the Tower again, lest I unwittingly reveal too much to those who would be better left ignorant."

ʃi lɛf ðət steɪtmən hæŋɪŋ bɪfɔɹ wɔkɪŋ tə ðə dɔɹ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ dɪdn stɑp hɝ, ðoʊ hi dɪd wɑtʃ wɪð ðoʊz səspɪʃəs aɪz ə hɪz. ʃi wʌndɝd huz wɔɹɾɝ i wɑz - ʃi dɪdn bɪliv ɛni ʌv ðə sɪstɝz ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum hæd wɔɹɾɝz, ðoʊ ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən. pɝhæps i bɪlɔŋ tə wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ spaɪz sɛn fɹəm sɑlədɑɹ, ən hæd bɪn dʒɹæftɪd baɪ sɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz.

She left that statement hanging before walking to the door. The Warder didn't stop her, though he did watch with those suspicious eyes of his. She wondered whose Warder he was - she didn't believe any of the sisters inside the room had Warders, though she wasn't certain. Perhaps he belonged to one of the other spies sent from Salidar, and had been drafted by Saerin and the others.

ðət wəɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪz dɪspəzɪʃən.

That would explain his disposition.

maɪdɑni kwɪkli fɑloʊɾ ɛɡwin fɹəm ðə ɹum, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɑɹɡjəmən əɹ sɛnʃɝ tə flaɪ aʊt bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɪmpli pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt.

Meidani quickly followed Egwene from the room, glancing over her shoulder, as if expecting argument or censure to fly out behind her. The Warder simply pulled the door shut.

"aɪ kæn bɪliv jə səksiɾəd," ðə ɡɹeɪ sɛd. "ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv stʃɹʌŋ jə ʌp baɪ jəɹ hilz ən hæd jə haʊlɪŋ!"

"I can't believe you succeeded," the Gray said. "They should have strung you up by your heels and had you howling!"

"ðeɪ ɑɹ tu waɪz fəɹ ðæt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðeɪɹ ði oʊnli wʌnz ɪn ðɪs blæstəd taʊɝ -  bɪsaɪdz meɪbi sɪlviænə - hu hæv ɛniθɪŋ ɹɪzɛmbəlɪŋ hɛdz sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz."

"They are too wise for that," Egwene said. "They're the only ones in this blasted Tower -  besides maybe Silviana - who have anything resembling heads sitting atop their shoulders."

"sɪlviænə?" maɪdɑni æskt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz. "dʌznt ʃi bit jə ɛvɹi deɪ?"

"Silviana?" Meidani asked with surprise. "Doesn't she beat you every day?"

"sɛvɹəl taɪmz ə deɪ," ɛɡwin sɛɾ æbsənli. "ʃiz vɛɹi duɾifəl, nɑt tə mɛnʃən θɔtfəl. ɪf wi hæd mɔɹ laɪk hɝ, ðə taʊɝ wʊdn əv ɡɑɾən tə ðɪs steɪɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs."

"Several times a day," Egwene said absently. "She's very dutiful, not to mention thoughtful. If we had more like her, the Tower wouldn't have gotten to this state in the first place."

maɪdɑni ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɛɡwin, ən ɑɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. "ju ɹɪli ɑɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn," ʃi faɪnəli sɛd. ɪt wɑz ən ɑd kɑmɛnt. hædnt ʃi dʒʌst swɔɹn ðət ʃi æksɛptɪɾ ɛɡwinz əθɔɹəɾi?

Meidani regarded Egwene, an odd expression on her face. "You really are the Amyrlin," she finally said. It was an odd comment. Hadn't she just sworn that she accepted Egwene's authority?

"kʌm ɑn," ɛɡwin sɛd, heɪsənɪŋ əɹ peɪs. "aɪ nid tə ɡɛt bæk bɪfɔɹ ðoʊz ɹɛdz ɡɹoʊ səspɪʃəs."

"Come on," Egwene said, hastening her pace. "I need to get back before those Reds grow suspicious."

tʃæptɝ θɝtin

CHAPTER 13

ən ɔfɝ ən ə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ɡɔɪn stʊd, sɔɹɾ ət ðə ɹɛɾi, feɪsɪŋ daʊn tu wɔɹɾɝz. ðə bɑɹn lɛɾ ɪn slɑts ə laɪt, ɛɹ spɑɹklɪŋ wɪð dʌst ən bɪts ə stʃɹɔ kɪkt ʌp fɹəm ðə faɪɾɪŋ. ɡɔɪn bæk sloʊli əkɹɔs ðə pæk dɝt flɔɹ, pæsɪŋ θɹu pætʃəz ə laɪt. ði ɛɹ wɑz wɔɹm ɑn ɪz skɪn. tʃɹɪkəlz ə swɛt ɹæn daʊn fɹəm ɪz tɛmpəlz, bʌɾ ɪz ɡɹɪp wɑz fɝm əz ðə tu wɔɹɾɝz ədvænst ɑn hɪm.

An Offer and a Departure Gawyn stood, sword at the ready, facing down two Warders. The barn let in slots of light, air sparkling with dust and bits of straw kicked up from the fighting. Gawyn backed slowly across the packed dirt floor, passing through patches of light. The air was warm on his skin. Trickles of sweat ran down from his temples, but his grip was firm as the two Warders advanced on him.

ðə wʌn ɪn fɹʌnt wɑz slit, ə lɪmbɝ, lɔŋ-ɑɹmd mæn wɪð ɹʌf-hjun fitʃɝz. ɪn ðə bɑɹnz ənivən laɪt, hɪz feɪs lʊk laɪk ən ənfɪnɪʃt wɝk wʌn maɪt faɪn ɪn ə skʌlptɝz wɝkʃɑp, wɪð lɔŋ ʃædoʊz əkɹɔs ɪz aɪz, hɪz tʃɪn dɪvaɪɾəd baɪ ə klft, hɪz noʊz kɹʊkəd fɹəm biɪŋ bɹoʊkən ən nɑt hild. hi wɔɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ ən blæk saɪdbɝnz.

The one in front was Sleete, a limber, long-armed man with rough-hewn features. In the barn's uneven light, his face looked like an unfinished work one might find in a sculptor's workshop, with long shadows across his eyes, his chin divided by a cleft, his nose crooked from being broken and not Healed. He wore long hair and black sideburns.

hɑtɔɹi hæd bɪn kwaɪt plizd wən əɹ wɔɹɾɝ hæd faɪnəli ɝaɪvd ət dɔɹlən; ʃid lɔst ɪm ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, ən ɪz stɔɹi wɑz ðə sɔɹt ɡlimən ən bɑɹdz sæŋ əbaʊt. slit hæd leɪn wundəd fəɹ aʊɝz bɪfɔɹ dɪlɪɹiəsli mænɪdʒɪŋ tə ɡɹæb ɪz hɔɹsəz ɹeɪnz ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. ɪt hæd lɔɪəli kæɹid hɪm, nɪɹ ʌnkɑnʃəs, fəɹ aʊɝz bɪfɔɹ ɝaɪvɪŋ əɾ ə nɪɹbaɪ vɪlədʒ. ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz ðəɹ hæd bɪn tɛmptəd tə sɛl slit tə ə loʊkəl bæn ə bændəts - ðɛɹ liɾɝ hæd vɪzəɾəd ɝliɝ pɹɑməsɪŋ əm seɪfti əz ə ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ ɹɪvilɪŋ ɛni ɹɛfjudʒiz fɹəm ðə nɪɹbaɪ bæɾəl. haʊɛvɝ, ðə meɪɝz dɔɾɝ hæɾ ɑɹɡjud fəɹ slits laɪf, kənvɪnsɪŋ əm ðət ðə bændəts mʌs bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ sikɪŋ wundəd wɔɹɾɝz. ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz hæd tʃoʊzən tə haɪd sliɾ ɪnstɛd, ən ðə ɡɝl hæd nɝst ɪm tə seɪfti.

Hattori had been quite pleased when her Warder had finally arrived at Dorlan; she'd lost him at Dumai's Wells, and his story was the sort gleemen and bards sang about. Sleete had lain wounded for hours before deliriously managing to grab his horse's reins and pull himself into the saddle. It had loyally carried him, near unconscious, for hours before arriving at a nearby village. The villagers there had been tempted to sell Sleete to a local band of bandits - their leader had visited earlier promising them safety as a reward for revealing any refugees from the nearby battle. However, the mayor's daughter had argued for Sleete's life, convincing them that the bandits must be Darkfriends if they were seeking wounded Warders. The villagers had chosen to hide Sleete instead, and the girl had nursed him to safety.

slit hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə snik əweɪ wʌns i wɑz wɛl ɪnʌf tə tʃɹævəl; ðə ɡɝl hæɾ əpɛɹənli teɪkən kwaɪɾ ə laɪkɪŋ tə hɪm. wɪspɝz əmʌŋ ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz sɛd ðət slits ɪskeɪp hæɾ ɔlsoʊ kʌm kəz i hæd bɪɡʌn filɪŋ əfɛkʃən fəɹ ðə ɡɝl hɪmsɛlf. moʊst wɔɹɾɝz nu bɛɾɝ ðən tə lɛt ðɛmsɛlvz ɡɹoʊ ətætʃt. slit hæd lɛft ɪn ðə naɪt, æftɝ ðə ɡɝl ən əɹ fæmli fɛl əslip - bʌɾ ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ðə vɪlədʒəz mɝsi, hid hʌntəd daʊn ðə bændəts ən sin tə ɪt ðət ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ pleɪɡ ðə vɪlədʒ əɡɛn.

Sleete had been forced to sneak away once he was well enough to travel; the girl had apparently taken quite a liking to him. Whispers among the Younglings said that Sleete's escape had also come because he had begun feeling affection for the girl himself. Most Warders knew better than to let themselves grow attached. Sleete had left in the night, after the girl and her family fell asleep - but in return for the village's mercy, he'd hunted down the bandits and seen to it that they would never plague the village again.

ɪt wɑz ðə mɛɹoʊ ʌv stɔɹiz ən lɛdʒənz - ət list, əmʌŋ ɹɛɡjəlɝ, lɛsɝ mɛn. fəɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ, slits stɔɹi wɑz ɔlmoʊs kɑmənpleɪs. mɛn laɪk ɪm ətʃɹæktəd lɛdʒənz əz ɔɹɾənɛɹi mɛn ətʃɹæktəd fliz. ɪn fækt, slit hædnt wɑntəd tə ʃɛɹ ɪz teɪl; ɪt hæd kʌm aʊɾ oʊnli oʊɪŋ tə ə vɪɡɝəs kæmpeɪn ə kwɛstʃənz fɹəm ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz. hi stɪl æktəɾ əz ɪf ɪz sɝvaɪvəl wɝ nʌθɪŋ tə bɹæɡ əbaʊt. hi wɑz ə wɔɹɾɝ. sɝvaɪvɪŋ əɡɛns ði ɑdz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn dɪlɪɹiəm oʊvɝ maɪlz ə ɹʌf tɝeɪn, kʌɾɪŋ daʊn ən ɪntaɪɝ bæn ə θivz wɪð wunz nɑt fʊli hild - ðiz wɝ dʒʌs ðə sɔɹts ə θɪŋz jə dɪd wən jə wɝ ə wɔɹɾɝ.

It was the marrow of stories and legends - at least, among regular, lesser men. For a Warder, Sleete's story was almost commonplace. Men like him attracted legends as ordinary men attracted fleas. In fact, Sleete hadn't wanted to share his tale; it had come out only owing to a vigorous campaign of questions from the Younglings. He still acted as if his survival were nothing to brag about. He was a Warder. Surviving against the odds, riding in delirium over miles of rough terrain, cutting down an entire band of thieves with wounds not fully healed - these were just the sorts of things you did when you were a Warder.

ɡɔɪn ɹɪspɛktɪd ðɛm. ivən ðə wʌnz i hæd kɪld. ɪspɛʃli ðə wʌnz i hæd kɪld. ɪt tʊk ə junik kaɪndə mæn tə ʃoʊ ðɪs kaɪndə dɛɾəkeɪʃən, ðɪs kaɪndə vɪdʒələns. ðɪs kaɪndə hjumɪlɪɾi.

Gawyn respected them. Even the ones he had killed. Especially the ones he had killed. It took a unique kind of man to show this kind of dedication, this kind of vigilance. This kind of humility.

waɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd ðə wɝld ən mɑnstɝz laɪk ælθɹ ɡɑt ðə ɡlɔɹi, mɛn laɪk slit kwaɪətli dɪd ðə wɝk ə hɪɹoʊz, itʃ ən ɛvɹi deɪ. wɪθaʊt ɡlɔɹi əɹ ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝd, ɪt wɑz juʒəwəli oʊnli baɪ əsoʊsieɪʃən wɪð ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. əɹ ɪt wɑz baɪ ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz.

While Aes Sedai manipulated the world and monsters like al'Thor got the glory, men like Sleete quietly did the work of heroes, each and every day. Without glory or recognition. If they were remembered, it was usually only by association with their Aes Sedai. Or it was by other Warders.

jə dɪdn fɝɡɛt jəɹ oʊn.

You didn't forget your own.

sliɾ ətækt, sɔɹd lænsɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ə stʃɹeɪt θɹʌs dɪlɪvɝd fəɹ mæksəməm spid. ðə vaɪpɝ flɪks ɪts tʌŋ, ə boʊl stʃɹaɪk, meɪd mɔɹ ɪfɛktɪv kəz slit fɔɾ ɪn tændəm wɪð ðə nɛɹoʊ, ʃɔɹt mæn ɹaʊndɪŋ təwɔɹd ɡɔɪnz lɛft. mɑɹlɪʃ wɑz ði oʊnli ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝ ɪn dɔɹlən - ən ɪz ɝaɪvəl hæd bɪn fɑɹ lɛs dʒɹəmæɾɪk ðən slits. mɑɹlɪʃ hæd bɪn wɪð ði ɝɪdʒənəl ɡɹup ʌv ɪlɛvən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæɾ ɪskeɪp dəməaɪz wɛlz, ən i hæd steɪd wɪð əm ði ɪntaɪɝ taɪm. hɪz oʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ə pɹɪɾi jʌŋ dəmɑni ɡɹin neɪm væʃə, wɑtʃt aɪdli fɹəm ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɑɹn.

Sleete attacked, sword lancing forward in a straight thrust delivered for maximum speed. The Viper Flicks Its Tongue, a bold strike, made more effective because Sleete fought in tandem with the narrow, short man rounding toward Gawyn's left. Marlesh was the only other Warder in Dorlan - and his arrival had been far less dramatic than Sleete's. Marlesh had been with the original group of eleven Aes Sedai who had escaped Dumai's Wells, and he had stayed with them the entire time. His own Aes Sedai, a pretty young Domani Green named Vasha, watched idly from the side of the barn.

ɡɔɪn kaʊntɝd ðə vaɪpɝ flɪks ɪts tʌŋ wɪð kæt dænsəz ɑn ðə wɔl, nɑkɪŋ əsaɪd ðə stʃɹaɪk ən ɡoʊɪŋ fəɹ ðə lɛɡz ɪn wʌn swip. ɪt wɑzn ɪntɛndəd tə hɪt, haʊɛvɝ; ɪt wɑz ə dɪfɛnsɪv muv, mɛn tə ɛneɪbəl ɪm tə kip ən aɪ ɑn boʊθ əpoʊnəns. mɑɹlɪʃ tʃɹaɪd lɛpɝdz kɝɛs, bʌt ɡɔɪn muvd ɪndə foʊldɪŋ ði ɛɹ, kɛɹfəli nɑkɪŋ əsaɪd ðə bloʊ ən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ fɹəm slit, hu wɑz ðə mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ə ðə tu. slit ɹipəzɪʃənd, teɪkɪŋ smuð stɛps, hɪz bleɪd tə ðə saɪɾ əz i sɛɾ ɪz bæk tə ðə mæsɪv paɪlz ə heɪ ət ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə stʌfi bɑɹn.

Gawyn countered The Viper Flicks Its Tongue with Cat Dances on the Wall, knocking aside the strike and going for the legs in one sweep. It wasn't intended to hit, however; it was a defensive move, meant to enable him to keep an eye on both opponents. Marlesh tried Leopard's Caress, but Gawyn moved into Folding the Air, carefully knocking aside the blow and waiting for another from Sleete, who was the more dangerous of the two. Sleete repositioned, taking smooth steps, his blade to the side as he set his back to the massive piles of hay at the rear of the stuffy barn.

ɡɔɪn muvd ɪndə kæɾ ɑn hɑt sæn əz mɑɹlɪʃ tʃɹaɪd hʌmɪŋbɝd kɪsəz ðə hʌniɹoʊz.

Gawyn moved into Cat on Hot Sand as Marlesh tried Hummingbird Kisses the Honeyrose.

hʌmɪŋbɝd wɑzn ðə ɹaɪt fɔɹm tə juz ɪn sətʃ ən ətæk; ɪt wɑz ɹɛɹli jusfəl əɡɛnst sʌmwʌn ɑn ðə dɪfɛnsɪv, bʌt mɑɹlɪʃ wɑz ɑbviəsli taɪɝɾ ə biɪŋ pɛɹid. hi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ iɡɝ. ɡɔɪn kəd juz ðæt. ən wʊd.

Hummingbird wasn't the right form to use in such an attack; it was rarely useful against someone on the defensive, but Marlesh was obviously tired of being parried. He was getting eager. Gawyn could use that. And would.

slit wɑz ədvænsɪŋ əɡɛn. ɡɔɪn bɹɔɾ ɪz sɔɹd bæk ɪn tə ɡɑɹɾ əz ðə wɔɹɾɝz əpɹoʊtʃt ɪn tændəm. ɡɔɪn ɪmiɾiətli muvd ɪndə æpəl blɑsəmz ɪn ðə waɪnd. hɪz bleɪd flæʃt θɹi taɪmz, pʊʃɪŋ ə waɪd-aɪd mɑɹlɪʃ bæk. mɑɹlɪʃ kɝst, θɹoʊɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fɔɹwɝd, bʌt ɡɔɪn bɹɔɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə pɹiviəs fɔɹm ən muv fludli ɪndə ʃeɪk du fɹəm ðə bɹæntʃ. hi stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə ə sɪɹiz ə sɪks ʃɑɹp bloʊz, θɹi əɾ itʃ əpoʊnənt, nɑkɪŋ mɑɹlɪʃ bæk ən tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd - ðə mæn hæd stɛp bæk ɪndə ðə faɪt tu kwɪkli - ən fɔɹsɪŋ slits bleɪɾ əsaɪd twaɪs, ðən ɛndɪŋ wɪð ɪz bleɪɾ əɡɛns ðə mænz nɛk.

Sleete was advancing again. Gawyn brought his sword back in to guard as the Warders approached in tandem. Gawyn immediately moved into Apple Blossoms in the Wind. His blade flashed three times, pushing a wide-eyed Marlesh back. Marlesh cursed, throwing himself forward, but Gawyn brought his sword up from the previous form and moved fluidly into Shake Dew from the Branch. He stepped forward into a series of six sharp blows, three at each opponent, knocking Marlesh back and to the ground - the man had stepped back into the fight too quickly - and forcing Sleete's blade aside twice, then ending with his blade against the man's neck.

ðə tu wɔɹɾɝz lʊkt ət ɡɔɪn, ʃɑkt. ðeɪ hæd bɔɹn sɪməlɝ ɪkspɹɛʃənz ðə læs taɪm ɡɔɪn hæd dɪfiɾəd ðɛm, ən ðə taɪm bɪfɔɹ ðæt. slit kæɹiɾ ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪɾ ən wɑz nɪɹ- lɛdʒəndɛɹi ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ fəɹ ɪz pɹaʊəs. hi wɑz sɛd tə hæv bɛstɪɾ ivən læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən twaɪs aʊɾ ə sɛvən baʊts, bæk wən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən hæd bɪn noʊn tə spɑɹ wɪð ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz.

The two Warders looked at Gawyn, shocked. They had borne similar expressions the last time Gawyn had defeated them, and the time before that. Sleete carried a heron-mark blade and was near- legendary in the White Tower for his prowess. He was said to have bested even Lan Mandragoran twice out of seven bouts, back when Mandragoran had been known to spar with other Warders.

mɑɹlɪʃ wɑzn əz ɹɪnaʊn əz ɪz kəmpænjən, bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl ə fʊli keɪpəbəl ən tʃɹeɪnd wɔɹɾɝ, noʊ izi foʊ.

Marlesh wasn't as renowned as his companion, but he was still a fully capable and trained Warder, no easy foe.

bʌt ɡɔɪn hæd wʌn. əɡɛn. θɪŋz sim soʊ sɪmpəl wən i wɑz spɑɹɪŋ. ðə wɝl kɑntʃɹæktəd daʊn - kəmpɹɛs laɪk bɛɹiz skwiz fəɹ ðɛɹ dʒus - ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ smɔlɝ ən iziɝ tə si fɹəm ʌp kloʊz. ɔl ɡɔɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ wɑntəd wɑz tə pɹətɛkt ɪleɪn. hi wɑntəd tə dɪfɛn ændɝ. meɪbi lɝn tə bi ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ laɪk ɡɑləd.

But Gawyn had won. Again. Things seemed so simple when he was sparring. The world contracted down - compressed like berries squeezed for their juice - into something smaller and easier to see from up close. All Gawyn had ever wanted was to protect Elayne. He wanted to defend Andor. Maybe learn to be a little more like Galad.

waɪ kʊdn laɪf bi əz sɪmpəl əz ə sɔɹd mætʃ? əpoʊnəns klɪɹ ən ɝeɪnʒd bɪfɔɹ ju. ðə pɹaɪz ɑbviəs: sɝvaɪvəl. wən mɛn fɔt, ðeɪ kənɛktəd. jə bɪkeɪm bɹʌðɝz əz jə tʃɹeɪɾɪd bloʊz.

Why couldn't life be as simple as a sword match? Opponents clear and arranged before you. The prize obvious: survival. When men fought, they connected. You became brothers as you traded blows.

ɡɔɪn ɹimuvd ɪz bleɪɾ ən stɛpt əweɪ, ʃiðɪŋ ɪt. hi ɔfɝɾ ə hæn tə mɑɹlɪʃ, hu tʊk ɪt, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ əz i stʊd. "ju ɑɹ ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd. laɪk ə kɹitʃɝ ə laɪt, kʌlɝ ən ʃædoʊ wən jə muv. aɪ fil laɪk ə beɪb hoʊldɪŋ ə stɪk wən aɪ feɪs ju."

Gawyn removed his blade and stepped away, sheathing it. He offered a hand to Marlesh, who took it, shaking his head as he stood. "You are remarkable, Gawyn Trakand. Like a creature of light, color and shadow when you move. I feel like a babe holding a stick when I face you."

slit sɛd nʌθɪŋ əz i ʃiðd ɪz oʊn sɔɹd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ɪz hɛd tə ɡɔɪn ɪn ɹɪspɛkt -  dʒʌst əz i hæd ðə læs tu taɪmz ðeɪd fɔt. hi wɑz ə mæn ə fju wɝdz. ɡɔɪn əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd ðæt.

Sleete said nothing as he sheathed his own sword, but he did nod his head to Gawyn in respect -  just as he had the last two times they'd fought. He was a man of few words. Gawyn appreciated that.

ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə bɑɹn ðəɹ wɑz ə hæf-bæɹəl fɪld wɪð wɔɾɝ, ən ðə mɛn wɔk tə ɪt.

In the corner of the barn there was a half-barrel filled with water, and the men walked to it.

kɔɹbɪt, wʌn ə ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz, hɝidli dɪpt ə leɪdlfəl ən hændəɾ ɪt tə ɡɔɪn. ɡɔɪn ɡeɪv ɪt tə slit. ði oʊldɝ mæn nɑɾəd əɡɛn ən tʊk ə dʒɹɪŋk waɪl mɑɹlɪʃ tʊk ə kʌp ɔf ðə dʌsti wɪndaʊsəl ən ɡɑt hɪmsɛlf ə dʒɹɪŋk. "aɪm seɪɪŋ, tʃɹəkənd," ðə ʃɔɹt mæn kəntɪnjud, "wil nid tə faɪn jə ə bleɪd wɪð səm hɛɹənz ɑn ɪt. noʊ wʌn ʃəɾ əv tə feɪs jə wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ wʌt ðəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪntu!"

Corbet, one of the Younglings, hurriedly dipped a ladleful and handed it to Gawyn. Gawyn gave it to Sleete. The older man nodded again and took a drink while Marlesh took a cup off the dusty windowsill and got himself a drink. "I'm saying, Trakand," the short man continued, "we'll need to find you a blade with some herons on it. No one should have to face you without knowing what they're getting into!"

"aɪm nɑɾ ə bleɪdmæstɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, teɪkɪŋ ðə leɪɾəl bæk fɹəm kɹʊk-noʊz sliɾ ən hævɪŋ ə dʒɹɪŋk. ɪt wɑz wɔɹm, wɪtʃ fɛlt ɡʊd. lɛs ʌv ə ʃɑk, mɔɹ nætʃɹəl.

"I'm not a blademaster," Gawyn said quietly, taking the ladle back from crook-nosed Sleete and having a drink. It was warm, which felt good. Less of a shock, more natural.

"ju kɪl hæmɝ, dɪdn ju?" mɑɹlɪʃ æskt.

"You killed Hammar, didn't you?" Marlesh asked.

ɡɔɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðə sɪmplɪsəɾi hid fɛl bɪfɔɹ, waɪl faɪɾɪŋ, wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi kɹʌmbəlɪŋ. "jɛs."

Gawyn hesitated. The simplicity he'd felt before, while fighting, was already crumbling. "Yes."

"wɛl, ðən jəɹ ə bleɪdmæstɝ," mɑɹlɪʃ sɛd. "ʃʊɾ əv teɪkən ɪz sɔɹd wən i fɛl."

"Well, then you're a blademaster," Marlesh said. "Should have taken his sword when he fell."

"ɪt wɑzn ɹɪspɛkfəl," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "bɪsaɪdz, aɪ dɪdn əv taɪm tə kleɪm pɹaɪzəz."

"It wasn't respectful," Gawyn said. "Besides, I didn't have time to claim prizes."

mɑɹlɪʃ læft, əz ɪf əɾ ə dʒoʊk, ðoʊ ɡɔɪn hædn ɪntɛndəd wʌn. hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ət slit, hu wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm wɪð kjʊɹiəs aɪz.

Marlesh laughed, as if at a joke, though Gawyn hadn't intended one. He glanced over at Sleete, who was watching him with curious eyes.

ə ɹʌsəl ə skɝts ənaʊns ði əpɹoʊtʃ ə væʃə. ðə ɡɹin hæd lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ ən stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ɡɹin aɪz ðəɾ ət taɪmz simd ɔlmoʊs kætlaɪk. "ɑɹ jə dʌn pleɪɪŋ, mɑɹlɪʃ?" ʃi æskt wɪð ə feɪnli dəmɑni æksɛnt.

A rustle of skirts announced the approach of Vasha. The Green had long black hair and striking green eyes that at times seemed almost catlike. "Are you done playing, Marlesh?" she asked with a faintly Domani accent.

mɑɹlɪʃ tʃʌkəld. "ju ʃəd bi hæpi tə si mi pleɪ, væʃə. aɪ sim tə ɹikɔl maɪ 'pleɪɪŋ'

Marlesh chuckled. "You should be happy to see me play, Vasha. I seem to recall my 'playing'

seɪvɪŋ jəɹ nɛk ə kʌpəl ə taɪmz ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild."

saving your neck a couple of times on the battlefield."

ʃi snɪft ən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. ɡɔɪn hæd ɹɛɹli sin ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝ wɪð əz kæʒəwəl ə ɹileɪʃənʃɪp əz ðiz tu. "kʌm," ʃi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ɑn əɹ hil ən wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ði oʊpən bɑɹn dɔɹz. "aɪ wɑnə si wʌɾ əz bɪn kipɪŋ nɛɹənwɪn ən ði ʌðɝz soʊ lɔŋ ɪndɔɹz. ɪt smɛlz ə dɪsɪʒənz biɪŋ meɪd."

She sniffed and raised an eyebrow. Gawyn had rarely seen an Aes Sedai and Warder with as casual a relationship as these two. "Come," she said, turning on her heel and walking toward the open barn doors. "I want to see what has been keeping Narenwin and the others so long indoors. It smells of decisions being made."

mɑɹlɪʃ ʃɹʌɡd ən tɔs ðə kʌp tə kɔɹbɪt. "wʌtɛvɝ ðəɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ, aɪ hoʊp ɪɾ ɪnvɑlvz muvɪŋ. aɪ doʊn laɪk sɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪn ðɪs vɪlədʒ wɪð ðoʊz soʊlʒɝz kɹipɪŋ ʌp ɑn ʌs. ɪf ɪt ɡɛts ɛni mɔɹ tɛns ɪn kæmp, aɪm laɪkli tə ɹʌn ɔf ən dʒɔɪn ðə tɪŋkɝz."

Marlesh shrugged and tossed the cup to Corbet. "Whatever they're deciding, I hope it involves moving. I don't like sitting around in this village with those soldiers creeping up on us. If it gets any more tense in camp, I'm likely to run off and join the Tinkers."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd ət ðət kɑmɛnt. ɪt hæd bɪn wiks sɪns hid læs dɛɹd sɛn ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz tə ɹeɪd. bɹaɪnz sɝtʃ pɑɹɾiz wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊsɝ ən kloʊsɝ tə ðə vɪlədʒ, ən ðəɾ əlaʊd fjuɝ ən fjuɝ ɹaɪdz aʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd.

Gawyn nodded at that comment. It had been weeks since he'd last dared send the Younglings to raid. Bryne's search parties were getting closer and closer to the village, and that allowed fewer and fewer rides out across the countryside.

væʃə pæst aʊt ðə dɔɹz, bʌt ɡɔɪn kəd stɪl hɪɹ əɹ seɪ, "ju kən saʊn laɪk sətʃ ə tʃaɪld ət taɪmz." mɑɹlɪʃ dʒʌst ʃɹʌɡd, weɪvɪŋ fɛɹwɛl tə ɡɔɪn ən slit bɪfɔɹ stɛpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə bɑɹn.

Vasha passed out the doors, but Gawyn could still hear her say, "You can sound like such a child at times." Marlesh just shrugged, waving farewell to Gawyn and Sleete before stepping out of the barn.

ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ɹifɪlɪŋ ðə leɪɾəl ən teɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ dʒɹɪŋk. "ðoʊz tu ɹimaɪn mi ʌv nʌθɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə bɹʌðɝ ən sɪstɝ ət taɪmz."

Gawyn shook his head, refilling the ladle and taking another drink. "Those two remind me of nothing so much as a brother and sister at times."

slit smaɪld.

Sleete smiled.

ɡɔɪn ɹipleɪs ðə leɪɾəl, nɑɾəd tə kɔɹbɪt, ðən muv tə liv. hi wɑntəd tə tʃɛk ɑn ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz' ivnɪŋ mil ən meɪk sɝɾən ɪt wɑz biɪŋ dɪstʃɹɪbjəɾəd pɹɑpɝli. səm ə ðə juðz hæd teɪkən tə spɑɹɪŋ ən pɹæktəsɪŋ wən ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn iɾɪŋ.

Gawyn replaced the ladle, nodded to Corbet, then moved to leave. He wanted to check on the Younglings' evening meal and make certain it was being distributed properly. Some of the youths had taken to sparring and practicing when they should have been eating.

əz i lɛft, haʊɛvɝ, slit ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən tʊk ɪz ɑɹm. ɡɔɪn lʊk bæk ɪn sɝpɹaɪz.

As he left, however, Sleete reached out and took his arm. Gawyn looked back in surprise.

"hɑtɔɹi oʊnli hæz wʌn wɔɹɾɝ," ðə mæn sɛɾ ɪn ɪz ɡɹævəli, sɑf vɔɪs.

"Hattori only has one Warder," the man said in his gravelly, soft voice.

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd. "ðæts nɑɾ ənhɝd-ʌv fəɹ ə ɡɹin."

Gawyn nodded. "That's not unheard-of for a Green."

"ɪɾ ɪzən kəz ʃi ɪzən oʊpən tə hævɪŋ mɔɹ," slit sɛd. "jɪɹz əɡoʊ, wən ʃi bɑndəd mi, ʃi sɛd ðət ʃi wəɾ oʊnli teɪk ənʌðɝ ɪf aɪ dʒʌdʒd ɪm wɝði. ʃi æsk mi tə sɝtʃ. ʃi dʌzn θɪŋk mʌtʃ ɑn ðiz kaɪnz ə θɪŋz. tu bɪzi wɪð ʌðɝ mæɾɝz."

"It isn't because she isn't open to having more," Sleete said. "Years ago, when she bonded me, she said that she would only take another if I judged him worthy. She asked me to search. She doesn't think much on these kinds of things. Too busy with other matters."

ɔl ɹaɪt, ɡɔɪn θɔt, wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ hi wɑz biɪŋ toʊl ðɪs.

All right, Gawyn thought, wondering why he was being told this.

slit tɝnd, miɾɪŋ ɡɔɪnz aɪz. "ɪts bɪn oʊvɝ tɛn jɪɹz, bʌɾ aɪv faʊn sʌmwʌn wɝði.

Sleete turned, meeting Gawyn's eyes. "It's been over ten years, but I've found someone worthy.

ʃɪl bɑn jə ðɪs aʊɝ, ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt."

She will bond you this hour, if you wish it."

ɡɔɪn blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz ət slit. ðə læŋki mæn wɑz ʃɹaʊɾɪd wʌns mɔɹ ɪn ɪz kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk, wɛɹɪŋ nɑndɪskɹɪp bɹaʊn ən ɡɹin bɪniθ. ʌðɝz kəmpleɪn ðət kəz ə hɪz lɔŋ hɛɹ ən saɪdbɝnz, slit lʊk mɔɹ skɹʌfi ðən ə wɔɹɾɝ ʃʊd. bʌt "skɹʌfi" wɑz ðə ɹɔŋ tɝm fəɹ ðɪs mæn. ɹʌf, pɝhæps, bʌt nætʃɹəl. laɪk ʌnkʌt stoʊnz əɹ ə nɑɹld - jɛt stɝɾi - oʊk.

Gawyn blinked in surprise at Sleete. The lanky man was shrouded once more in his color-shifting cloak, wearing nondescript brown and green beneath. Others complained that because of his long hair and sideburns, Sleete looked more scruffy than a Warder should. But "scruffy" was the wrong term for this man. Rough, perhaps, but natural. Like uncut stones or a gnarled - yet sturdy - oak.

"aɪm ɑnɝd, slit," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ keɪm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə stʌɾi kəz ʌv ændɔɝən tʃɹədɪʃənz, nɑt kəz aɪ wɑz gɑnə bi ə wɔɹɾɝ. maɪ pleɪs ɪz bɪsaɪd maɪ sɪstɝ." ən ɪf ɛniwʌn ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ tə bɑn mi, ɪɾəl bi ɛɡwin.

"I'm honored, Sleete," Gawyn said. "But I came to the White Tower to study because of Andoran traditions, not because I was going to be a Warder. My place is beside my sister." And if anyone is going to bond me, it will be Egwene.

"ju keɪm fəɹ ðoʊz ɹizənz," slit sɛd, "bʌt ðoʊz ɹizənz əv pæst. juv fɔɾ ɪn əɹ wɔɹ, juv kɪld wɔɹɾɝz ən dɪfɛndəd ðə taʊɝ. jə ɑɹ wʌn ʌv ʌs. jə bɪlɔŋ wɪð ʌs."

"You came for those reasons," Sleete said, "but those reasons have passed. You've fought in our war, you've killed Warders and defended the Tower. You are one of us. You belong with us."

ɡɔɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

Gawyn hesitated.

"ju sɝtʃ," slit sɛd. "laɪk ə hɔk, ɡlænsɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə pɝtʃ əɹ tə hʌnt. jəl taɪɝ ə flaɪɪŋ ɪvɛntʃəwəli. dʒɔɪn ʌs, ən bɪkʌm wʌn ʌv ʌs. jəl faɪn ðət hɑtɔɹi ɪz ə ɡʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. waɪzɝ ðən moʊst, fɑɹ lɛs pɹoʊn tə skwɑbəlz əɹ fulɪʃnəs ðən mɛni ɪn ðə taʊɝ."

"You search," Sleete said. "Like a hawk, glancing this way and that, trying to decide whether to perch or to hunt. You'll tire of flying eventually. Join us, and become one of us. You'll find that Hattori is a good Aes Sedai. Wiser than most, far less prone to squabbles or foolishness than many in the Tower."

"aɪ kænt, slit," ɡɔɪn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "ændɝ. . . ."

"I can't, Sleete," Gawyn said, shaking his head. "Andor. . . ."

"hɑtɔɹi ɪz nɑt ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əz ɪnfluɛntʃəl baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ," slit sɛd. "ði ʌðɝz ɹɛɹli kɛɹ wʌt ʃi dʌz. tə hæv ju, ʃid si hɝsɛlf əsaɪn tə ændɝ. jə kəɾ əv boʊθ, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd. θɪŋk ɑn ɪt."

"Hattori is not regarded as influential by the White Tower," Sleete said. "The others rarely care what she does. To have you, she'd see herself assigned to Andor. You could have both, Gawyn Trakand. Think on it."

ɡɔɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əɡɛn, ðən nɑɾəd. "vɛɹi wɛl. əl θɪŋk ɑn ɪt."

Gawyn hesitated again, then nodded. "Very well. I'll think on it."

slit ɹilist ɪz ɑɹm. "æz mʌtʃ əz ə mæn kən æsk."

Sleete released his arm. "As much as a man can ask."

ɡɔɪn muv tə liv, bʌt ðən stɑpt, lʊkɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd sliɾ ɪn ðə dʌsti bɑɹn. ðən ɡɔɪn dʒɛstʃɝd təwɔɹd kɔɹbɪɾ ən dʒɛstʃɝd wɪð ə kɝt saɪn. liv ən wɑtʃ, ɪt mɛnt. ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋ nɑɾəd iɡɝli - hi wɑz wʌn ə ðə jʌŋɡəst əmʌŋ ðɛm, ɔlweɪz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə də tə pɹuv hɪmsɛlf. hid wɑtʃ ðə dɔɹz ən ɡɪv wɔɹnɪŋ ɪf ɛniwʌn əpɹoʊtʃt.

Gawyn moved to leave, but then stopped, looking back toward Sleete in the dusty barn. Then Gawyn gestured toward Corbet and gestured with a curt sign. Leave and watch, it meant. The Youngling nodded eagerly - he was one of the youngest among them, always looking for something to do to prove himself. He'd watch the doors and give warning if anyone approached.

slit wɑtʃt wɪð kjʊɹiɑsəɾi əz kɔɹbɪt pəzɪʃən hɪmsɛlf, hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. ɡɔɪn ðən stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən spoʊk mɔɹ kwaɪətli, tu sɑft fəɹ kɔɹbɪt tə hɪɹ. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ʌv wʌt hæpən ɪn ðə taʊɝ, slit?"

Sleete watched with curiosity as Corbet positioned himself, hand on his sword. Gawyn then stepped forward and spoke more quietly, too soft for Corbet to hear. "What do you think of what happened in the Tower, Sleete?"

ðə ɹʌf mæn fɹaʊnd, ðən stɛp bæk ən lin əɡɛns ði ɪnsaɪd bɑɹn wɔl. wɪð ə ɡlæns dʊɹɪŋ ðə kæʒəwəl muv, slit tʃɛkt aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ tə meɪk sɝɾən noʊbɑdi wɑz lɪsnɪŋ fɹəm ðət saɪd.

The rough man frowned, then stepped back and leaned against the inside barn wall. With a glance during the casual move, Sleete checked out the window to make certain nobody was listening from that side.

"ɪts bæd," slit faɪnəli sɛd, toʊn hʌʃt. "wɔɹɾɝ ʃʊdn faɪt wɔɹɾɝ. ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃʊdn faɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃəd nɛvɝ hæpən. nɑt naʊ. nɑɾ ɛvɝ."

"It's bad," Sleet finally said, tone hushed. "Warder shouldn't fight Warder. Aes Sedai shouldn't fight Aes Sedai. Should never happen. Not now. Not ever."

"bʌɾ ɪt dɪd," ɡɔɪn sɛd.

"But it did," Gawyn said.

slit nɑɾəd.

Sleete nodded.

"ænd naʊ wiv ɡɑt tu dɪfɹənt ɡɹups ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɡɔɪn kəntɪnjud, "wɪð tu dɪfɹən ɑɹmiz, wʌn bɪsidʒɪŋ ði ʌðɝ."

"And now we've got two different groups of Aes Sedai," Gawyn continued, "with two different armies, one besieging the other."

"dʒʌs kip jəɹ hɛd daʊn," slit sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ hɑt tɛmpɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ waɪz maɪnz əz wɛl. ðəl də ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ."

"Just keep your head down," Sleete said. "There are hot tempers in the Tower, but there are wise minds as well. They'll do the right thing."

"wɪtʃ ɪz?"

"Which is?"

"ɛn ɪt," slit sɛd. "wɪð kɪlɪŋ ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi, ʌðɝ weɪz ɪf pɑsəbəl. nʌθɪŋ ɪz wɝθ ðɪs dɪvɪʒən. nʌθɪŋ."

"End it," Sleete said. "With killing if necessary, other ways if possible. Nothing is worth this division. Nothing."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd.

Gawyn nodded.

slit ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "maɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi dɪdn laɪk ðə fil ə θɪŋz ɪn ðə taʊɝ. wɑntəd tə ɡɛɾ aʊt. ʃiz waɪz . . . waɪz ən kɹæfti. bʌt ʃiz ɔlsoʊ nɑɾ ɪnfluɛntʃəl, soʊ ði ʌðɝz doʊn lɪsən tə hɝ.

Sleete shook his head. "My Aes Sedai, she didn't like the feel of things in the Tower. Wanted to get out. She's wise . . . wise and crafty. But she's also not influential, so the others don't listen to her.

ɛɛs sədaɪ. səmtaɪmz, ɔl ðeɪ sim tə kɛɹ əbaʊɾ ɪz u kæɹiz ðə bɪɡəst stɪk."

Aes Sedai. Sometimes, all they seem to care about is who carries the biggest stick."

ɡɔɪn lin kloʊsɝ. wʌn ɹɛɹli hɝd tɔk əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹæŋkɪŋ ən ɪnfluəns. ðeɪ dɪdn əv ɹæŋks, laɪk ðə mɪlətɛɹi, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl ɪnstɪŋktɪvli nu hu əmʌŋ əm wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ. haʊ dɪɾ ɪt wɝk? slit sim tə hæv səm aɪdiə, bʌɾ i dɪdn tɔk fɝðɝ ɑn ɪt, soʊ ɪt wəɾ əv tə ɹɪmeɪn ə mɪstɝi fəɹ naʊ.

Gawyn leaned closer. One rarely heard talk about Aes Sedai ranking and influence. They didn't have ranks, like the military, but they all instinctively knew who among them was in charge. How did it work? Sleete seemed to have some idea, but he didn't talk further on it, so it would have to remain a mystery for now.

"hɑtɔɹi ɡɑɾ aʊt," slit kəntɪnjud sɔfli. "wɛn ɑn ðɪs mɪʃən tə ælθɹ, nɛvɝ noʊɪŋ ðə dɛpθ ʌv wʌɾ ɪt wɑz əbaʊt. ʃi dʒʌs dɪdnt wɑnə bi ɪn ðə taʊɝ. waɪz wʊmən." hi saɪd, stændɪŋ əpɹaɪɾ ən leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɡɔɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. "hæmɝ wɑz ə ɡʊd mæn."

"Hattori got out," Sleete continued softly. "Went on this mission to al'Thor, never knowing the depth of what it was about. She just didn't want to be in the Tower. Wise woman." He sighed, standing upright and laying a hand on Gawyn's shoulder. "Hammar was a good man."

"hi wɑz," ɡɔɪn sɛd, filɪŋ ə twɪst ɪn ɪz stʌmək.

"He was," Gawyn said, feeling a twist in his stomach.

"bʌɾ i wʊɾə kɪl ju," slit sɛd. "kɪl jə klinli ən kwɪkli. hi wɑz ðə wʌn ɑn ði əfɛnsɪv, nɑt ju. hi ʌndɝstʊd waɪ jə dɪd wʌt jə dɪd. noʊbɑdi meɪɾ ɛni ɡʊd dɪsɪʒənz ðət deɪ. ðəɹ wɝn ɛni ɡʊd dɪsɪʒənz tə bi meɪd."

"But he would have killed you," Sleete said. "Killed you cleanly and quickly. He was the one on the offensive, not you. He understood why you did what you did. Nobody made any good decisions that day. There weren't any good decisions to be made."

"aɪ . . ." ɡɔɪn dʒʌs nɑɾəd. "θæŋk ju."

"I . . ." Gawyn just nodded. "Thank you."

slit ɹimuvd ɪz hæn ən wɔk təwɔɹd ði ɛntʃɹəns. hi ɡlæns bæk, haʊɛvɝ. "sʌm seɪ ðət hɑtɔɹi ʃʊɾə ɡɔn bæk fəɹ mi," hi sɛd. "ðoʊz jʌŋɡəlɪŋz ə jʊɹz, ðeɪ θɪŋk ʃi əbændən mi ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. ʃi dɪdnt. ʃi nu aɪ lɪvd. ʃi nu aɪ hɝt. bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ tʃɹʌstɪd mi tə də maɪ duɾi waɪl ʃi dɪd hɝz. ʃi niɾəd tə ɡɛt nuz tə ðə ɡɹinz ʌv wʌt hæd hæpən ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, ʌv wʌt ði æmɪɝlɪnz tʃɹu ɔɹɾɝz wɪð ælθɹ hæɾ ɪnteɪld. aɪ niɾəd tə sɝvaɪv. wi dɪɾ əɹ duɾi. bʌt wʌns ðət mɛsədʒ hæd bɪn sɛnt, ɪf ʃi hædn fɛl mi əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɑn maɪ oʊn, ʃi wʊɾə kʌm fəɹ mi. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt. ən wi boʊθ noʊ ɪt."

Sleete removed his hand and walked toward the entrance. He glanced back, however. "Some say that Hattori should have gone back for me," he said. "Those Younglings of yours, they think she abandoned me at Dumai's Wells. She didn't. She knew I lived. She knew I hurt. But she also trusted me to do my duty while she did hers. She needed to get news to the Greens of what had happened at Dumai's Wells, of what the Amyrlin's true orders with al'Thor had entailed. I needed to survive. We did our duty. But once that message had been sent, if she hadn't felt me approaching on my own, she would have come for me. No matter what. And we both know it."

wɪð ðæt, hi lɛft. ɡɔɪn wɑz lɛf θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ðə kjʊɹiəs pɑɹɾɪŋ wɝdz. slit wɑz ɔfən ən ɑd wʌn tə tɔk tə. əz fluəɾ əz i wɑz əz ə sɔɝdzmən, hi dɪdn meɪk kɑnvɝseɪʃən smuðli.

With that, he left. Gawyn was left thinking on the curious parting words. Sleete was often an odd one to talk to. As fluid as he was as a swordsman, he didn't make conversation smoothly.

ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, livɪŋ ðə bɑɹn ən weɪvɪŋ kɔɹbɪt fɹi ʌv wɑtʃ duɾi. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv ɡɔɪn əɡɹiɪŋ tə bɪkʌm hɑtɔɹiz wɔɹɾɝ. ði ɔfɝ hæd bɪn tɛmptɪŋ fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit, bʌɾ oʊnli əz ə weɪ ʌv ɪskeɪpɪŋ ɪz pɹɑbləmz. hi nu ðəɾ i wəd nɑt bi hæpi əz əɹ wɔɹɾɝ, əɹ ɛniwʌnz wɔɹɾɝ seɪv ɛɡwinz.

Gawyn shook his head, leaving the barn and waving Corbet free of watch duty. There was no possibility of Gawyn agreeing to become Hattori's Warder. The offer had been tempting for a heartbeat, but only as a way of escaping his problems. He knew that he would not be happy as her Warder, or anyone's Warder save Egwene's.

hid pɹɑməst ɛɡwin ɛniθɪŋ. ɛniθɪŋ, əz lɔŋ əz ɪt dɪdn hɝɾ ændɝ əɹ ɪleɪn. laɪt, hid pɹɑməst əɹ nɑt tə kɪl ælθɹ. ət list, nɑɾ əntɪl æftɝ ɡɔɪn kəd pɹuv fəɹ sɝɾən ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən hæd kɪld ɪz mʌðɝ. waɪ kʊdn ɛɡwin si ðət ðə mæn ʃid ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð hæd tɝn ɪndə ə mɑnstɝ, twɪstəd baɪ ðə wʌn paʊɝ? ælθɹ niɾəd tə bi pʊt daʊn. fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðɛm ɔl.

He'd promised Egwene anything. Anything, as long as it didn't hurt Andor or Elayne. Light, he'd promised her not to kill al'Thor. At least, not until after Gawyn could prove for certain that the Dragon had killed his mother. Why couldn't Egwene see that the man she'd grown up with had turned into a monster, twisted by the One Power? Al'Thor needed to be put down. For the good of them all.

ɡɔɪn klɛntʃt ən ənklɛntʃt ɪz fɪst, stɔkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə vɪlədʒ sɛntɝ, wɪʃɪŋ i kəɾ ɪkstɛn ðə pis ən stɪlnəs ə sɔɹd faɪɾɪŋ tə ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz laɪf. ði ɛɹ wɑz pʌnʒənt wɪð ðə sɛn ə kaʊz ən dʌŋ fɹəm ðə bɑɹnz; hi wəd bi ɡlæd tə ɡɛt bæk tə ə pɹɑpɝ sɪɾi. dɔɹlənz saɪz ən ɹimoʊtnəs maɪt meɪk ɪɾ ə ɡʊd pleɪs tə haɪd, bʌt ɡɔɪn stʃɹɔŋli wɪʃt ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə hæd tʃoʊzən ə lɛs oʊɾɝəs pleɪs tə haʊs ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz. hɪz kloʊðɪŋ sim laɪkli tə kæɹi ðə sɛn ə kæɾəl fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz deɪz - əsumɪŋ ðə ɹɛbəl ɑɹmi dɪdn dɪskʌvɝ ən slɔɾɝ əm ɔl ɪn ðə nɛks fju wiks.

Gawyn clenched and unclenched his fist, stalking across the village center, wishing he could extend the peace and stillness of sword fighting to the rest of his life. The air was pungent with the scent of cows and dung from the barns; he would be glad to get back to a proper city. Dorlan's size and remoteness might make it a good place to hide, but Gawyn strongly wished that Elaida had chosen a less odorous place to house the Younglings. His clothing seemed likely to carry the scent of cattle for the rest of his days - assuming the rebel army didn't discover and slaughter them all in the next few weeks.

ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz i əpɹoʊtʃt ðə meɪɝz haʊs. ðə tu-stɔɹi bɪldɪŋ hæɾ ə pikt ɹuf ən sæɾ ət ðə vɛɹi sɛntɝ ə ðə vɪlədʒ. ðə meɪn bɑɾi ʌv ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz wɑz kæmpt ɪn ðə smɔl fild aʊt bɪhaɪn ðə bɪldɪŋ. wʌns, ðət pætʃ hæd ɡɹoʊn blækbɛɹiz, bʌt ðə tu-hɑt sʌmɝ fɑloʊd baɪ ðə blɪzɝɾ ʌv ə wɪntɝ hæd kɪl ðə bʊʃəz. ðeɪ wɝ wʌn ə mɛni kæʒəwəltiz ðət wɝ gɑnə lid tə ən ivən hɑɹʃɝ wɪntɝ ðɪs jɪɹ.

Gawyn shook his head as he approached the mayor's house. The two-story building had a peaked roof and sat at the very center of the village. The main body of the Younglings was camped in the small field out behind the building. Once, that patch had grown blackberries, but the too-hot summer followed by the blizzard of a winter had killed the bushes. They were one of many casualties that were going to lead to an even harsher winter this year.

ðə fild wɑzn ðə bɛs pleɪs tə kæmp - ðə mɛn wɝ kɑnstənli ɡɹʌmpɪŋ əbaʊt pɪkɪŋ blækbɛɹi θɔɹnz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ skɪn - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz kloʊs tə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə vɪlədʒ waɪl jɛt sʌmwʌt sɪkluɾɪd. ə fju θɔɹnz wɝ wɝθ ðə kənvinjəns.

The field wasn't the best place to camp - the men were constantly grumping about picking blackberry thorns out of their skin - but it was close to the center of the village while yet somewhat secluded. A few thorns were worth the convenience.

tə ɹitʃ ðə fild, ɡɔɪn hæd tə kʌɾ əkɹɔs ði ənpeɪvd vɪlədʒ skwɛɹ ən pæs baɪ ðə kənæl ðət ɹæn pæs ðə fɹʌn ə ðə meɪɝz haʊs. hi nɑɾəd tə ə ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən wɑʃɪŋ kloʊðz ðɛɹ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd ɹɪkɹuɾɪd əm tə də ðə wɑʃ fəɹ ðə sɪstɝz ən fəɹ ɡɔɪnz ɔfəsɝz. ðə peɪ wɑz smɔl fəɹ soʊ mʌtʃ wɝk, ən ɡɔɪn ɡeɪv ðə wɪmən wʌt lɪɾəl ɛkstʃɹə hi kəɾ əfɔɹɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz oʊn pɑkət, ə dʒɛstʃɝ ðət hæɾ ɝn ɪm læftɝ fɹəm nɛɹənwɪn sədaɪ, bʌt θæŋks fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒ wɪmən. ɡɔɪnz mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz tɔt ðət ðə wɝkɝz wɝ ðə spaɪn ʌv ə kɪŋdəm; bɹeɪk ðɛm, ən jud sun faɪn ðət jə kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ muv. ðɪs sɪɾiz pipəl maɪt nɑt bi hɪz sɪstɝz sʌbʒɪkts, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt si ðɛm teɪkən ædvæntɪdʒ ə baɪ hɪz tʃɹups.

To reach the field, Gawyn had to cut across the unpaved village square and pass by the canal that ran past the front of the mayor's house. He nodded to a group of women washing clothes there. The Aes Sedai had recruited them to do the wash for the sisters and for Gawyn's officers. The pay was small for so much work, and Gawyn gave the women what little extra he could afford out of his own pocket, a gesture that had earned him laughter from Narenwin Sedai, but thanks from the village women. Gawyn's mother had always taught that the workers were the spine of a kingdom; break them, and you'd soon find that you could no longer move. This city's people might not be his sister's subjects, but he would not see them taken advantage of by his troops.

hi pæs ðə meɪɝz hoʊm, noʊɾɪŋ ðə kloʊzd ʃʌɾɝz ɑn ðə wɪndoʊz. mɑɹlɪʃ laʊnʒd aʊtsaɪd, hɪz pətiɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ stændɪŋ wɪð hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps ən skaʊlɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ. əpɛɹənli, ʃi hæd bɪn ɹəfjuzd ɛntʃɹi. waɪ? væʃə dɪdn əv ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə ɹæŋk əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ wɑzn əz loʊ əz hɑtɔɹi. ɪf væʃə hæd bɪn dɪnaɪɾ ɛntʃɹəns . . . wɛl, pɝhæps ðəɹ wɝ ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɝdz biɪŋ ʃɛɹɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə bɪldɪŋ. ðət meɪd ɡɔɪn kjʊɹiəs.

He passed the mayor's home, noting the closed shutters on the windows. Marlesh lounged outside, his petite Aes Sedai standing with hands on her hips and scowling at the door. Apparently, she had been refused entry. Why? Vasha didn't have a great deal of rank among the Aes Sedai, but she also wasn't as low as Hattori. If Vasha had been denied entrance . . . well, perhaps there were important words being shared inside the building. That made Gawyn curious.

hɪz mɛn wʊɾə ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt - ɹeɪjɹ wʊɾə toʊld ɪm ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪznəs wɑz bɛs lɛf tə ðɛɹ kɑnfɝənsəz, wɪθaʊɾ ənwɔntɪɾ ɪɹz flæpɪŋ tə meɪk ə mɛs ə θɪŋz. ðət wɑz wʌn ɹizən ðət ɡɔɪn wʊdn meɪk ə ɡʊd wɔɹɾɝ. hi dɪdn tʃɹʌst ɛɛs sədaɪ. hɪz mʌðɝ hæd, ən lʊk wɛɹ ðət hæd ɡɑɾən hɝ. ən haʊ ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd tʃɹiɾəd ɪleɪn ən ɛɡwin . . . wɛl, hi maɪt səpɔɹt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ i sɝɾənli dɪdn tʃɹʌs ðɛm.

His men would have ignored it - Rajar would have told him that Aes Sedai business was best left to their conferences, without unwanted ears flapping to make a mess of things. That was one reason that Gawyn wouldn't make a good Warder. He didn't trust Aes Sedai. His mother had, and look where that had gotten her. And how the White Tower had treated Elayne and Egwene . . . well, he might support the Aes Sedai, but he certainly didn't trust them.

hi ɹaʊndəd ðə bæk ə ðə bɪldɪŋ, ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə pɝfəkli lədʒɪɾəmət ɪnspɛkʃən ə ðə ɡɑɹdz.

He rounded the back of the building, going about a perfectly legitimate inspection of the guards.

moʊst ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ dɪdn əv wɔɹɾɝz - iðɝ ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛdz əɹ ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz bɪhaɪnd. səm fju wɝ oʊld ɪnʌf tə hæv lɔst wɔɹɾɝz tə eɪdʒ ən nɛvɝ tʃoʊzən nu wʌnz. tu ənfɔɹtʃənət wɪmən hæd lɔs ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. ɡɔɪn ən ði ʌðɝz dɪd ðɛɹ bɛs tə pɹitɛn ðeɪ dɪdnt noʊɾəs ðə ɹɛɾ aɪz əɹ əkeɪʒənəl sɑbz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ ɹumz.

Most of the Aes Sedai in the village didn't have Warders - either they were Reds or they had left their Warders behind. Some few were old enough to have lost Warders to age and never chosen new ones. Two unfortunate women had lost their Warders at Dumai's Wells. Gawyn and the others did their best to pretend they didn't notice the red eyes or occasional sobs coming from their rooms.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, kleɪm ðət ðeɪ dɪdnt nid ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋ ɡɑɹdz əz pɹətɛkʃən. ðeɪ wɝ pɹɑbli ɹaɪt. bʌt ɡɔɪn hæd sin dɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz; ðeɪ wɝn ɪnvɪnsəbəl.

The Aes Sedai, of course, claimed that they didn't need the Youngling guards as protection. They were probably right. But Gawyn had seen dead Aes Sedai at Dumai's Wells; they weren't invincible.

ət ðə bæk dɔɹz, hæl mɔɪɹ səluɾəd ən lɛt ɡɔɪn ɛntɝ tə kəntɪnju hɪz ɪnspɛkʃən. ɡɔɪn stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp ə ʃɔɹt, stʃɹeɪt sɛɾ ə stɛɹz ən ɛntɝd ði ʌpɝ hɔlweɪ. ðɛɹ, hi ɹɪliv bɝɾən, ðə dɑɹk- skɪn tɛɹən jʌŋɡəlɪŋ u wɑz ɑn wɑtʃ. bɝɾən wɑz ən ɔfəsɝ, ən ɡɔɪn toʊld ɪm tə ɡoʊ tʃɛk ɑn ðə fud dɪstʃɹəbjuʃən ɪn ðə kæmp. ðə mæn nɑɾəd, ðən lɛft.

At the back doors, Hal Moir saluted and let Gawyn enter to continue his inspection. Gawyn strode up a short, straight set of stairs and entered the upper hallway. There, he relieved Berden, the dark- skinned Tairen Youngling who was on watch. Berden was an officer, and Gawyn told him to go check on the food distribution in the camp. The man nodded, then left.

ɡɔɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ɪn fɹʌn ə nɛɹənwɪn sədaɪz ɹum. ɪf i wɑntəd tə hɪɹ wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn bɪtwin ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ði ɑbviəs θɪŋ tə də wəd bi tə ivzdʒɹɑp. bɝɾən hæd bɪn ði oʊnli ɡɑɹɾ ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, ən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wɔɹɾɝz tə pɹətɛkt əɡɛnst ənwɔntɪɾ ɪɹz. bʌt ðə θɔɾ ə lɪsnɪŋ ɪn lɛft ə saʊɝ teɪst ɪn ɡɔɪnz maʊθ. hi ʃʊdn əv tə ivzdʒɹɑp. hi wɑz ðə kəmændɝ ə ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ teɪkɪŋ ɡʊɾ ædvæntɪdʒ ə hɪz tʃɹups. ðeɪ oʊɾ ɪm ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ðɛɹfɔɹ, ɹæðɝ ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪsən, hi ɡeɪv ə fɝm nɑk ɑn ðə dɔɹ.

Gawyn hesitated in front of Narenwin Sedai's room. If he wanted to hear what was going on between the Aes Sedai, the obvious thing to do would be to eavesdrop. Berden had been the only guard on the second floor, and there were no Warders to protect against unwanted ears. But the thought of listening in left a sour taste in Gawyn's mouth. He shouldn't have to eavesdrop. He was the commander of the Younglings, and the Aes Sedai were taking good advantage of his troops. They owed him information. Therefore, rather than trying to listen, he gave a firm knock on the door.

ðə nɑk wɑz mɛt baɪ saɪləns. ðən ðə dɔɹ kɹæk tə ʃoʊ ə slɪvɝ ə koʊvɑɹləz fɹaʊnɪŋ feɪs. ðə laɪt-hɛɹd ɹɛd hæd bɪn ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə sɪɾi bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ dɪspleɪst, bʌt ʃi wɑz stɪl wʌn ə ðə mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɪmən ɪn dɔɹlən.

The knock was met by silence. Then the door cracked to show a sliver of Covarla's frowning face. The light-haired Red had been in charge of the sisters in the city before being displaced, but she was still one of the more important women in Dorlan.

"wi wɝ nɑt tə bi ɪntɝʌptɪd," ʃi snæp θɹu ðə slɪvɝ ʌv oʊpən dɔɹweɪ. "jɔɹ soʊlʒɝz hæɾ ɔɹɾɝz tə kip ɛvɹiwʌn aʊt, ivən ʌðɝ sɪstɝz."

"We were not to be interrupted," she snapped through the sliver of open doorway. "Your soldiers had orders to keep everyone out, even other sisters."

"ðoʊz ɹulz doʊn əplaɪ tə mi," ɡɔɪn sɛd, miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz. "maɪ mɛn ɑɹ ɪn sɪɹiəs deɪnʒɝ ɪn ðɪs vɪlədʒ. ɪf jə woʊn lemi bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə plænɪŋ, ðən aɪ dɪmæn ət lis tə bi eɪbəl tə lɪsən."

"Those rules don't apply to me," Gawyn said, meeting her eyes. "My men are in serious danger in this village. If you won't let me be part of the planning, then I demand at least to be able to listen."

koʊvɑɹləz ɪmpæsɪv feɪs sim tə ʃoʊ ənɔɪəns. "jɔɹ ɪmpuɾəns simz tə ɡɹoʊ baɪ ðə deɪ, tʃaɪld," ʃi sɛd. "pɝhæps jə nid tə bi ɹimuvd ən ə mɔɹ suɾəbəl ɹɪpleɪsmən ɹeɪz tə kæptən ðət ɡɹup."

Covarla's impassive face seemed to show annoyance. "Your impudence seems to grow by the day, child," she said. "Perhaps you need to be removed and a more suitable replacement raised to captain that group."

ɡɔɪn klɛntʃt ɪz dʒɔ.

Gawyn clenched his jaw.

"ju θɪŋk ðeɪ wʊdn sɛt jə əsaɪɾ ɪf ə sɪstɝ æskt ɪɾ ə ðɛm?" koʊvɑɹlə æskt, smaɪlɪŋ feɪnli. "ə sɑɹi ɪkskjus fəɹ ən ɑɹmi ðeɪ meɪ bi, bʌt ðeɪ noʊ ðɛɹ pleɪs. ə pɪɾi ðə seɪm kænɑt bi sɛd fəɹ ðɛɹ kəmændɝ. ɡoʊ bæk tə jəɹ mɛn, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd."

"You think they wouldn't set you aside if a sister asked it of them?" Covarla asked, smiling faintly. "A sorry excuse for an army they may be, but they know their place. A pity the same cannot be said for their commander. Go back to your men, Gawyn Trakand."

wɪð ðæt, ʃi ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ ɑn hɪm.

With that, she shut the door on him.

ɡɔɪn ɪtʃt tə fɔɹs ɪz weɪ ɪndə ðə ɹum. bʌt ðət wəd bi sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ fəɹ ɔl ʌv əbaʊt tu bɹɛθs, wɪtʃ wɑz haʊ lɔŋ ɪt wəd teɪk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə tʃɹʌs ɪm ʌp wɪð ðə paʊɝ. haʊ wəd ðət bi fəɹ ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz' mɝæl? siɪŋ ðɛɹ kəmændɝ, ðə bɹeɪv ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd, kæst aʊɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ wɪð ə ɡæɡ ʌv ɛɹ ɪn ɪz maʊθ? hi ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪz fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, tɝnɪŋ bæk daʊn ðə stɛɹz.

Gawyn itched to force his way into the room. But that would be satisfying for all of about two breaths, which was how long it would take the Aes Sedai to truss him up with the Power. How would that be for the Younglings' morale? Seeing their commander, the brave Gawyn Trakand, cast out of the building with a gag of Air in his mouth? He ignored his frustration, turning back down the stairs.

hi wɛn ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən ən lin əɡɛns ðə fɑɹ wɔl, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə stɛps tə ðə sɛkən flɔɹ. naʊ ðət hid ɹɪliv bɝɾən, hi fɛlt i niɾəd tə ɹɪmeɪn ɑn wɑtʃ hɪmsɛlf əɹ sɛn ə ɹʌnɝ tə fɛtʃ ənʌðɝ mæn. hi wɑntəd tə θɪŋk fəɹ ə fju moʊməns fɝst; ɪf ðɛɹ kɑnfɝəns əbʌv tʊk lɔŋ, hiɾ əpɔɪn ə ɹɪpleɪsmənt.

He went into the kitchen and leaned against the far wall, staring at the steps to the second floor. Now that he'd relieved Berden, he felt he needed to remain on watch himself or send a runner to fetch another man. He wanted to think for a few moments first; if their conference above took long, he'd appoint a replacement.

ɛɛs sədaɪ. sɛnsəbəl mɛn steɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm əm wən pɑsəbəl, ən oʊbeɪɾ əm wɪð əlækɹəɾi wən steɪɪŋ əweɪ wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. ɡɔɪn hæd tʃɹʌbəl duɪŋ iðɝ; hɪz blʌdlaɪn pɹɪvɛntɪd steɪɪŋ əweɪ, hɪz pɹaɪɾ ɪntɝfɪɹd wɪð oʊbeɪɪŋ ðɛm. hi hæd səpɔɹɾəd ɪleɪɾə ɪn ðə ɹɪbɛljən nɑt kəz i laɪkt əɹ - ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn koʊl dʊɹɪŋ əɹ jɪɹz æktɪŋ əz ɪz mʌðɝz ædvaɪzɝ. noʊ, hid səpɔɹɾəd əɹ kəz hid dɪslaɪk sɪuənz tʃɹitmən ə hɪz sɪstɝ ən ɛɡwin.

Aes Sedai. Sensible men stayed away from them when possible, and obeyed them with alacrity when staying away was impossible. Gawyn had trouble doing either; his bloodline prevented staying away, his pride interfered with obeying them. He had supported Elaida in the rebellion not because he liked her - she'd always been cold during her years acting as his mother's advisor. No, he'd supported her because he'd disliked Siuan's treatment of his sister and Egwene.

bʌt wəɾ ɪleɪɾə hæv tʃɹiɾəd ðə ɡɝlz ɛni bɛɾɝ? wəɾ ɛni ʌv əm hæv? ɡɔɪn hæd meɪɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən ɪn ə moʊmən ə pæʃən; ɪt hædn bɪn ðə kulhɛɾɪd ækt ə lɔɪəlti ðəɾ ɪz mɛn əsumd.

But would Elaida have treated the girls any better? Would any of them have? Gawyn had made his decision in a moment of passion; it hadn't been the coolheaded act of loyalty that his men assumed.

wɛɹ wɑz ɪz lɔɪəlti, ðɛn?

Where was his loyalty, then?

ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, fʊtstɛps ɑn ðə stɛɹz ən feɪn vɔɪsəz fɹəm ðə hɔlweɪ əbʌv ənaʊns ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd fɪnɪʃt ðɛɹ sikɹət kɑnfɝəns. koʊvɑɹlə keɪm daʊn ðə stɛɹz ɪn ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ, seɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə ðə sɪstɝz bɪhaɪn hɝ. ". . . kæn bɪliv ðə ɹɛbəlz sɛɾ ʌp ðɛɹ oʊn æmɪɝlɪn."

A few minutes later, footsteps on the stairs and faint voices from the hallway above announced that the Aes Sedai had finished their secret conference. Covarla came down the stairs in red and yellow, saying something to the sisters behind her. ". . . can't believe the rebels set up their own Amyrlin."

nɛɹənwɪn - θɪn ən skwɛɹ-feɪst - keɪm nɛkst, nɑɾɪŋ. ðɛn, ʃɑkɪŋli, keɪɾɝin ɔlɹuɾɪn wɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹwɛl bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ɡɔɪn stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, stʌnd. keɪɾɝin hæd lɛf ðə kæmp wiks bɪfɔɹ, ðə deɪ æftɝ nɛɹənwɪnz ɝaɪvəl. ðə ɹeɪvən-hɛɹd ɹɛd hæd nɑt bɪn pɑɹɾ ə ði ɝɪdʒənəl ɡɹup ðət wɑz ɔɹɾɝd tə dɔɹlən, ən hæd juz ðəɾ əz ən ɪkskjus tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Narenwin - thin and square-faced - came next, nodding. Then, shockingly, Katerine Alruddin walked out of the stairwell behind them. Gawyn stood up straight, stunned. Katerine had left the camp weeks before, the day after Narenwin's arrival. The raven-haired Red had not been part of the original group that was ordered to Dorlan, and had used that as an excuse to return to the White Tower.

wən hæd ʃi kʌm bæk tə dɔɹlən? haʊ hæd ʃi kʌm bæk? hɪz mɛn wʊɾə ɹipɔɹɾəd tə ɡɔɪn ɪf ðeɪd sin hɝ. hi daʊɾɪd ðə wɑtʃpoʊsts cʊɾə mɪst əɹ ɝaɪvəl.

When had she come back to Dorlan? How had she come back? His men would have reported to Gawyn if they'd seen her. He doubted the watchposts could have missed her arrival.

ʃi aɪd ɡɔɪn əz ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ pæs θɹu ðə kɪtʃən, smaɪlɪŋ slaɪli. ʃid noʊɾəst ɪz ʃɑk.

She eyed Gawyn as the three Aes Sedai passed through the kitchen, smiling slyly. She'd noticed his shock.

"jɛs," keɪɾɝin sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə koʊvɑɹlə. "ɪmædʒən ɪt - ən æmɪɝlɪn wɪθaʊɾ ən æktʃəwəl sit tə sɪɾ əpɑn! ðəɹ ə ɡɹup ə fulɪʃ ɡɝlz kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə tʃaɪlz pʌpət ʃoʊ wɪð dɑlz dʒɹɛst ʌp laɪk ðɛɹ bɛɾɝz. ʌv kɔɹs ðeɪ wəd pɪk ə waɪldɝ tə də ðə duɾi, ən ə mɪɹ æksɛptɪɾ ət ðæt. ðeɪ nu haʊ pəθɛɾɪk ðə dɪsɪʒən wɑz."

"Yes," Katerine said, turning to Covarla. "Imagine it - an Amyrlin without an actual seat to sit upon! They're a group of foolish girls creating a child's puppet show with dolls dressed up like their betters. Of course they would pick a wilder to do the duty, and a mere Accepted at that. They knew how pathetic the decision was."

"bʌɾ ət list ʃi wɑz kæptʃɝd," nɛɹənwɪn noʊɾəd, pɔzɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹweɪ əz koʊvɑɹlə pæs θɹu.

"But at least she was captured," Narenwin noted, pausing at the doorway as Covarla passed through.
