keɪɾɝin læft ʃɑɹpli. "kæptʃɝɾ ən meɪd tə haʊl hæf ðə deɪ. aɪ wʊdnt wɑnə bi ðəɾ ælvɪɹ ɡɝl ɹaɪt naʊ. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪts noʊ lɛs ðən ʃi dɪzɝvz fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ əm pʊt ði æmɪɝlɪnz ʃɔl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz."

Katerine laughed sharply. "Captured and made to howl half the day. I wouldn't want to be that al'Vere girl right now. Of course, it's no less than she deserves for letting them put the Amyrlin's shawl on her shoulders."

wʌt? ɡɔɪn θɔt wɪð ʃɑk.

What? Gawyn thought with shock.

ðə θɹi pæst aʊɾ ə ðə kɪtʃən, vɔɪsəz feɪɾɪŋ. ɡɔɪn bɛɹli noʊɾəst. hi stæɡɝd bæk, hɪɾɪŋ ðə wɔl fəɹ səpɔɹt. ɪt kʊdn bi! ɪt saʊndəd laɪk . . . ɛɡwin . . . hi hæd tə hæv mɪʃɝd!

The three passed out of the kitchen, voices fading. Gawyn barely noticed. He staggered back, hitting the wall for support. It couldn't be! It sounded like . . . Egwene . . . He had to have misheard!

bʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kʊdn laɪ. hid hɝd ɹumɝz ðət ðə ɹɛbəlz hæd ðɛɹ oʊn hɔl ən æmɪɝlɪn . . .

But Aes Sedai couldn't lie. He'd heard rumors that the rebels had their own Hall and Amyrlin . . .

bʌɾ ɛɡwin? ɪt wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs! ʃi wɑz oʊnli æksɛptɪd!

but Egwene? It was ridiculous! She was only Accepted!

bʌɾ u bɛɾɝ tə sɛɾ ʌp fəɹ ə pətɛnʃəl fɔl? pɝhæps nʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə pʊt ðɛɹ nɛks ɑn ðə laɪn baɪ teɪkɪŋ ðə taɪɾəl. ə jʌŋɡɝ wʊmən laɪk ɛɡwin wʊɾə meɪɾ ə pɝfək pɔn.

But who better to set up for a potential fall? Perhaps none of the sisters had been willing to put their necks on the line by taking the title. A younger woman like Egwene would have made a perfect pawn.

pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf təɡɛðɝ, ɡɔɪn hɝiɾ aʊɾ ə ðə kɪtʃən ən æftɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi pæst ɪndə ðə leɪɾ æftɝnun tə faɪn væʃə stændɪŋ, maʊθ dʒɹupɪŋ, əz ʃi stɛɹɾ ət keɪɾɝin. əpɛɹənli, ɡɔɪn wɑzn ði oʊnli wʌn ʃɑk baɪ ðə ɹɛdz sʌɾən ɹɪtɝn.

Pulling himself together, Gawyn hurried out of the kitchen and after the Aes Sedai. He passed into the late afternoon to find Vasha standing, mouth drooping, as she stared at Katerine. Apparently, Gawyn wasn't the only one shocked by the Red's sudden return.

ɡɔɪn kɑt tændoʊ, wʌn ə ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋ ɡɑɹdz ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə bɪldɪŋ, baɪ ði ɑɹm. "dɪd jə si hɝ ɛntɝ ðə bɪldɪŋ?"

Gawyn caught Tando, one of the Youngling guards at the front of the building, by the arm. "Did you see her enter the building?"

ðə jʌŋ ændɔɝən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd. wʌn ə ðə mɛn ɪnsaɪd ɹipɔɹɾəd siɪŋ əɹ mit wɪð ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ - ʃi keɪm daʊn aʊɾ ə ði æɾɪk sʌɾənli, ɪt simz. bʌt nʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz noʊz haʊ ʃi ɡɑɾ ɪn!"

The young Andoran shook his head. "No, my Lord. One of the men inside reported seeing her meet with the other Aes Sedai - she came down out of the attic suddenly, it seems. But none of the guards knows how she got in!"

ɡɔɪn ɹilis ðə soʊlʒɝ ən dæʃt æftɝ keɪɾɝin. hi kɑɾ ʌp tə ðə θɹi wɪmən ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə dʌsti taʊn skwɛɹ. ɔl θɹi tɝn eɪdʒləs feɪsəz təwɔɹd hɪm, wɛɹɪŋ aɪdɛntɪkəl θɪn- maʊð fɹaʊnz. koʊvɑɹləz aɪz wɝ pɝtɪkjəlɝ hɑɹʃ, bʌt ɡɔɪn dɪdn kɛɹ ɪf ðeɪ tʊk ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz fɹəm ɪm əɹ ɪf ðeɪ taɪɾ ɪm ʌp ɪn ɛɹ. hjumɪlieɪʃən dɪdn mæɾɝ. oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ mæɾɝd.

Gawyn released the soldier and dashed after Katerine. He caught up to the three women in the middle of the dusty town square. All three turned ageless faces toward him, wearing identical thin- mouthed frowns. Covarla's eyes were particular harsh, but Gawyn didn't care if they took the Younglings from him or if they tied him up in air. Humiliation didn't matter. Only one thing mattered.

"ɪz ɪt tʃɹu?" hi dɪmændəd. ðɛn, kɹɪŋɪŋ, hi fɔɹst ɹɪspɛkt ɪndə hɪz vɔɪs. "pliz, keɪɾɝin sədaɪ. ɪz ɪt tʃɹu wʌɾ aɪ oʊvɝhɝd jə seɪɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɹɛbəlz ən ðɛɹ æmɪɝlɪn?"

"Is it true?" he demanded. Then, cringing, he forced respect into his voice. "Please, Katerine Sedai. Is it true what I overheard you saying about the rebels and their Amyrlin?"

ʃi aɪd hɪm, mɛʒɝɪŋ hɪm. "aɪ səpoʊz ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd tə pæs ðɪs nuz əmʌŋ jəɹ soʊlʒɝz.

She eyed him, measuring him. "I suppose it would be good to pass this news among your soldiers.

jɛs, ðə ɹɛbəl æmɪɝlɪn əz bɪn kæptʃɝd."

Yes, the rebel Amyrlin has been captured."

"æn əɹ neɪm?" ɡɔɪn æskt.

"And her name?" Gawyn asked.

"ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "lɛt ðə ɹumɝz spɹɛd tʃɹuθ, fəɹ wʌns." ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɪm wɪð dɪsmɪsɪv kɝtnəs, ðən bɪɡæn wɔkɪŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ tu əɡɛn. "pʊt wʌɾ aɪ hæv tɔt jə tə ɡʊd juz. ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪnsɪsts ðət ðə ɹeɪdz bi stɛpt ʌp, ən ðiz wivz ʃəd lɛn jə ənpɹɛsɪdɛntɪd moʊbɪləɾi. doʊn bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf ðə ɹɛbəlz æntɪsəpeɪt ju, haʊɛvɝ. ðeɪ noʊ ðət wɪv ðɛɹ soʊ-kɔld æmɪɝlɪn, ən əv pɹɑbli ɡɛs ðət wɪv ðə nu wivz əz wɛl. ɪt woʊn bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪz hæd baɪ ɔl. jus ði ɛdʒ juv bɪn ɡɪvən bɪfɔɹ ɪt dʌlz."

"Egwene al'Vere," Katerine said. "Let the rumors spread truth, for once." She nodded to him with dismissive curtness, then began walking with the other two again. "Put what I have taught you to good use. The Amyrlin insists that the raids be stepped up, and these weaves should lend you unprecedented mobility. Don't be surprised if the rebels anticipate you, however. They know that we have their so-called Amyrlin, and have probably guessed that we have the new weaves as well. It won't be long before Traveling is had by all. Use the edge you've been given before it dulls."

ɡɔɪn wɑz bɛɹli lɪsnɪŋ. ə pis ə hɪz maɪnd wɑz ʃɑkt. tʃɹævlɪŋ? ə θɪŋ ə lɛdʒənz.

Gawyn was barely listening. A piece of his mind was shocked. Traveling? A thing of legends.

wɑz ðət haʊ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn wɑz kipɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmi səplaɪd?

Was that how Gareth Bryne was keeping his army supplied?

haʊɛvɝ, ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɡɔɪnz bɹeɪn wɑz stɪl nʌm. sɪuən sɑntʃ hæd bɪn stɪld ən sleɪɾɪd fəɹ ɛksəkjuʃən, ən ʃi hæd sɪmpli bɪn ə dɪpoʊzd æmɪɝlɪn. wʌt wəd ðeɪ də wɪð ə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn, ə liɾɝ ʌv ə ɹɛbəl fækʃən?

However, the greater part of Gawyn's brain was still numb. Siuan Sanche had been stilled and slated for execution, and she had simply been a deposed Amyrlin. What would they do with a false Amyrlin, a leader of a rebel faction?

meɪd tə haʊl hæf ðə deɪ. . . .

Made to howl half the day. . . .

ɛɡwin wɑz biɪŋ tɔɹtʃɝd. ʃi wəd bi stɪld! ʃi pɹɑbli hæd bɪn ɔlɹɛɾi. æftɝ ðæt, ʃi wəd bi ɛksəkjuɾəd. ɡɔɪn wɑtʃt ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɔk əweɪ. ðən i tɝn sloʊli, stʃɹeɪnʒli kɑm, leɪɪŋ ɪz hæn ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sɔɹd.

Egwene was being tortured. She would be stilled! She probably had been already. After that, she would be executed. Gawyn watched the three Aes Sedai walk away. Then he turned slowly, strangely calm, laying his hand on the pommel of his sword.

ɛɡwin wɑz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl. hi blɪŋk dɪlɪbɝətli, stændɪŋ ɪn ðə skwɛɹ, kæɾəl kɔlɪŋ dɪstənli, wɔɾɝ bʌbəlɪŋ ɪn ðə kənæl bɪsaɪd hɪm.

Egwene was in trouble. He blinked deliberately, standing in the square, cattle calling distantly, water bubbling in the canal beside him.

ɛɡwin wəd bi ɛksəkjuɾəd.

Egwene would be executed.

wɛɹ ɪz jəɹ lɔɪəlti, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd?

Where is your loyalty, Gawyn Trakand?

hi kɹɔs ðə vɪlədʒ, wɔkɪŋ wɪð ə stʃɹeɪnʒli ʃʊɹ stɛp. ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz wəd bi ʌnɹɪlaɪəbəl ɪn ən ækʃən əɡɛns ðə waɪt taʊɝ. hi kʊdn juz əm tə maʊn ə ɹɛskju. bʌɾ i wɑz ənlaɪkli tə bi eɪbəl tə mænədʒ wʌn ɑn ɪz oʊn. ðət lɛft ɪm wɪð oʊnli wʌn ɑpʃən.

He crossed the village, walking with a strangely sure step. The Younglings would be unreliable in an action against the White Tower. He couldn't use them to mount a rescue. But he was unlikely to be able to manage one on his own. That left him with only one option.

tɛn mɪnəts leɪɾɝ faʊn ɪm ɪn ɪz tɛnt, kɛɹfəli pækɪŋ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. moʊst ə hɪz θɪŋz wəɾ əv tə steɪ. ðəɹ wɝ fɑɹ skaʊɾ aʊtpoʊsts, ən i hæd vɪzəɾəd əm bɪfɔɹ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz ɪnspɛkʃənz.

Ten minutes later found him in his tent, carefully packing his saddlebags. Most of his things would have to stay. There were far scout outposts, and he had visited them before in surprise inspections.

ðət wəd meɪk ə ɡʊɾ ɪkskjus fəɹ ɪm tə liv ðə kæmp.

That would make a good excuse for him to leave the camp.

hi kʊdn ɝaʊz səspɪʃənz. koʊvɑɹlə wɑz ɹaɪt. ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz fɑloʊd hɪm. ðeɪ ɹɪspɛktɪd hɪm. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɪz - ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən wəd tɝn ɑn ɪm əz kwɪkli əz i hæd tɝn ɑn hæmɝ ɪf ɪt wɝ ðə wɪl ə ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɪf ɛni ʌv əm ɡɑɾ ə hɪn ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz plænɪŋ, hi wʊdn mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɑɹdz əweɪ.

He couldn't arouse suspicions. Covarla was right. The Younglings followed him. They respected him. But they were not his - they belonged to the White Tower, and would turn on him as quickly as he had turned on Hammar if it were the will of the Amyrlin. If any of them got a hint of what he was planning, he wouldn't manage to get a hundred yards away.

hi kloʊzd ən lætʃt ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. ðət wəɾ əv tə du. hi pʊʃt ɪz weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt, slɪŋɪŋ ðə bæɡz oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ðən meɪɾ ɪz weɪ təwɔɹd ðə hɔɹs laɪnz. əz i wɔkt, hi flæɡd daʊn ɹeɪjɹ, hu wɑz ʃoʊɪŋ ə skwɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝz səm ədvænst sɔɹdpleɪ tɛkniks.

He closed and latched his saddlebags. That would have to do. He pushed his way out of the tent, slinging the bags over his shoulder, then made his way toward the horse lines. As he walked, he flagged down Rajar, who was showing a squad of soldiers some advanced swordplay techniques.

ɹeɪjɹ sɛɾ ənʌðɝ mæn ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, ðən hɝiɾ oʊvɝ tə ɡɔɪn, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə sæɾəlbæɡz.

Rajar set another man in charge, then hurried over to Gawyn, frowning at the saddlebags.

"aɪm gɑnə ɪnspɛk ðə fɔɹθ aʊtpoʊst," ɡɔɪn sɛd.

"I'm going to inspect the fourth outpost," Gawyn said.

ɹeɪjɹ ɡlænst ət ðə skaɪ; ɪt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi dɪmɪŋ. "soʊ leɪt?"

Rajar glanced at the sky; it was already dimming. "So late?"

"læs taɪm aɪ ɪnspɛktɪɾ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. ɑd, haʊ hɪz hɑɹt wɑzn ɹeɪsɪŋ. kɑm ən ivən. "taɪm bɪfɔɹ ðæt, ɪt wɑz ði æftɝnun. bʌt ðə moʊs deɪnʒɝəs taɪm tə bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪz ivnɪŋ, wən ɪts stɪl laɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ən ətæk bʌt leɪɾ ɪnʌf ðət mɛn ɑɹ taɪɝɾ ən fʊl ə sʌpɝ."

"Last time I inspected in the morning," Gawyn said. Odd, how his heart wasn't racing. Calm and even. "Time before that, it was the afternoon. But the most dangerous time to be surprised is evening, when it's still light enough for an attack but late enough that men are tired and full of supper."

ɹeɪjɹ nɑɾəd, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɡɔɪn əz i wɔkt. "laɪt noʊz wi niɾ əm fəɹ wɑtʃfəl skaʊts naʊ," hi əɡɹid. bɹaɪnz oʊn skaʊts hæd bɪn ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾɪŋ vɪlədʒəz nɑt hæf ə deɪz ɹaɪd fɹəm dɔɹlən. "aɪl ɡɛt jə ən ɛskɔɹt."

Rajar nodded, joining Gawyn as he walked. "Light knows we need them for watchful scouts now," he agreed. Bryne's own scouts had been investigating villages not half a day's ride from Dorlan. "I'll get you an escort."

"nɑt niɾəd," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "læs taɪm, aʊtpoʊs fɔɹ sɔ mi kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ə ɡʊd hæf ə maɪl. ə skwɑd ɹeɪzəz tu mʌtʃ dʌst. aɪ wɑnə si haʊ kin ðɛɹ aɪz ɑɹ wən ɪts dʒʌst wʌn ɹaɪɾɝ."

"Not needed," Gawyn said. "Last time, Outpost Four saw me coming from a good half a mile. A squad raises too much dust. I want to see how keen their eyes are when it's just one rider."

ɹeɪjɹ fɹaʊn əɡɛn.

Rajar frowned again.

"aɪl bi seɪf," ɡɔɪn sɛd, fɔɹsɪŋ aʊɾ ə ɹaɪ smaɪl. "ɹeɪjɹ, jə noʊ əl bi. wʌt? ɑɹ jə əfɹeɪɾ əl bi teɪkən baɪ bændəts?"

"I'll be safe," Gawyn said, forcing out a wry smile. "Rajar, you know I will be. What? Are you afraid I'll be taken by bandits?"

ɹeɪjɹ ɹɪlækst, tʃʌklɪŋ. "ju? ðeɪd sunɝ kætʃ slit. ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn. bʌt meɪk sɝɾən tə sɛn ə mɛsənʒɝ fəɹ mi wən jə ɡɛt bæk ɪndə kæmp. əl steɪ ʌp hæf ðə naɪt wɝiɪŋ ɪf jə doʊn ɹɪtɝn."

Rajar relaxed, chuckling. "You? They'd sooner catch Sleete. All right, then. But make certain to send a messenger for me when you get back into camp. I'll stay up half the night worrying if you don't return."

sɑɹi tə kɑs jə ðə slip ðɛn, maɪ fɹɛnd, ɡɔɪn θɔt, nɑɾɪŋ. ɹeɪjɹ ɹæn bæk tə supɝvaɪz ðə spɑɹɪŋ, ən ɡɔɪn sun faʊn hɪmsɛlf dʒʌst aʊtsaɪd ðə kæmp, ənduɪŋ tʃælənʒəz hɑbəl əz ə vɪlədʒ bɔɪ - dʌbəlɪŋ əz ə steɪbəlɪhænd - fɛtʃt ɪz sæɾəl.

Sorry to cost you the sleep then, my friend, Gawyn thought, nodding. Rajar ran back to supervise the sparring, and Gawyn soon found himself just outside the camp, undoing Challenge's hobble as a village boy - doubling as a stablehand - fetched his saddle.

"ju hæv ðə lʊk ʌv ə mæn u hæz meɪɾ ʌp ɪz maɪnd," ə kwaɪət vɔɪs sɛd sʌɾənli.

"You have the look of a man who has made up his mind," a quiet voice said suddenly.

ɡɔɪn spʌn, hæn fɔlɪŋ tə hɪz sɔɹd. wʌn ə ðə ʃædoʊz nɪɹbaɪ wɑz muvɪŋ. lʊkɪŋ kloʊsli, hi wɑz eɪbəl tə meɪk aʊt ðə fɔɹm ʌv ə ʃæɾoʊd mæn wɪð ə kɹʊkəd noʊz. kɝs ðoʊz wɔɹɾɝ kloʊks!

Gawyn spun, hand falling to his sword. One of the shadows nearby was moving. Looking closely, he was able to make out the form of a shadowed man with a crooked nose. Curse those Warder cloaks!

ɡɔɪn tʃɹaɪd tə feɪn kæʒəɑlnəs əz i hæd wɪð ɹeɪjɹ. "hæpi tə hæv sʌmθɪŋ tə du, aɪ səpoʊz," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ fɹəm sliɾ əz ðə steɪbəlbɔɪ əpɹoʊtʃt. ɡɔɪn tɔst ɪm ə kɑpɝ ən tʊk ðə sæɾəl hɪmsɛlf, dɪsmɪsɪŋ ðə bɔɪ.

Gawyn tried to feign casualness as he had with Rajar. "Happy to have something to do, I suppose," he said, turning from Sleete as the stableboy approached. Gawyn tossed him a copper and took the saddle himself, dismissing the boy.

slit kəntɪnjud tə wɑtʃ fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ə mæsɪv paɪn əz ɡɔɪn pʊt ðə sæɾəl ɑn tʃælənʒəz bæk. ðə wɔɹɾɝ nu. ɡɔɪnz æk hæd fuld ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, bʌɾ i kəd sɛns ðəɾ ɪt wʊdnt wɝk ɑn ðɪs mæn. laɪt! wɑz i gɑnə hæv tə kɪl ənʌðɝ mæn i ɹɪspɛktɪd? bɝn ju, ɪleɪɾə! bɝn ju, sɪuən sɑntʃ, ən jəɹ ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ. stɑp juzɪŋ pipəl. stɑp juzɪŋ mi!

Sleete continued to watch from the shadow of a massive pine as Gawyn put the saddle on Challenge's back. The Warder knew. Gawyn's act had fooled everyone else, but he could sense that it wouldn't work on this man. Light! Was he going to have to kill another man he respected? Burn you, Elaida! Burn you, Siuan Sanche, and your entire Tower. Stop using people. Stop using me!

"wɛn ʃæl aɪ tɛl jəɹ mɛn ðət jə ɑɹən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ?" sliɾ æskt.

"When shall I tell your men that you aren't returning?" Sleete asked.

ɡɔɪn pʊl ðə sæɾəl stʃɹæps taɪɾ ən weɪɾəd fəɹ ɪz hɔɹs tə ɪksheɪl. hi lʊkt oʊvɝ tʃælənʒ, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "ju doʊn plæn tə stɑp mi?"

Gawyn pulled the saddle straps tight and waited for his horse to exhale. He looked over Challenge, frowning. "You don't plan to stop me?"

slit tʃʌkəld. "aɪ fɔt jə θɹaɪs tədeɪ ən dɪdnt wɪn ə sɪŋɡəl baʊt, ɔlðoʊ aɪ hæɾ ə ɡʊd mæn tə lɛn mi eɪd. juv ðə lʊk əbaʊt jə ʌv ə mæn u wɪl kɪl ɪf niɾəd, ən aɪ doʊn θɝs fəɹ dɛθ soʊ iɡɝli əz səm maɪɾ əsum."

Sleete chuckled. "I fought you thrice today and didn't win a single bout, although I had a good man to lend me aid. You have the look about you of a man who will kill if needed, and I don't thirst for death so eagerly as some might assume."

"jud faɪt mi," ɡɔɪn sɛd, faɪnəli duɪŋ ʌp ðə sæɾəl ən lɪftɪŋ ðə bæɡz ɪndə pleɪs, taɪɪŋ əm ɑn. tʃælənʒ snɔɹɾɪd. ðə hɔɹs nɛvɝ dɪd laɪk kæɹiɪŋ ɛkstʃɹə weɪt. "jud daɪ ɪf jə θɔɾ ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. ɪf jə ətækt, ivən ɪf aɪ kɪl ju, ɪt wəd ɹeɪz ə ɹʌkəs. aɪd nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə ɪkspleɪn waɪ aɪd kɪld ə wɔɹɾɝ. jə kəd stɑp mi."

"You'd fight me," Gawyn said, finally doing up the saddle and lifting the bags into place, tying them on. Challenge snorted. The horse never did like carrying extra weight. "You'd die if you thought it was necessary. If you attacked, even if I killed you, it would raise a ruckus. I'd never be able to explain why I'd killed a Warder. You could stop me."

"tʃɹu," slit sɛd.

"True," Sleete said.

"ðɛn waɪ lemi ɡoʊ?" ɡɔɪn sɛd, ɹaʊndɪŋ ðə ɡɛldɪŋ ən teɪkɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz. hi mɛt ðoʊz ʃæɾoʊd aɪz ən θɔɾ i kɑt ðə feɪntəs hɪn ʌv ə smaɪl ɑn ðə lɪps bɪniθ ðɛm.

"Then why let me go?" Gawyn said, rounding the gelding and taking the reins. He met those shadowed eyes and thought he caught the faintest hint of a smile on the lips beneath them.

"pɝhæps aɪ dʒʌs laɪk tə si mɛn kɛɹ," slit sɛd. "pɝhæps aɪ hoʊp jəl faɪn ə weɪ tə hɛlp ɛn ðɪs. pɝhæps aɪm filɪŋ leɪzi ən sɔɹ wɪð ə bɹuz spɪɹət fɹəm soʊ mɛni dɪfits. meɪ jə faɪnd wʌt jə sik, jʌŋ tʃɹəkənd." ən wɪð ə ɹʌsəl ə ðə kloʊk, slit wɪθdʒɹu, feɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs ʌv ɔnkʌmɪŋ naɪt.

"Perhaps I just like to see men care," Sleete said. "Perhaps I hope you'll find a way to help end this. Perhaps I am feeling lazy and sore with a bruised spirit from so many defeats. May you find what you seek, young Trakand." And with a rustle of the cloak, Sleete withdrew, fading into the darkness of oncoming night.

ɡɔɪn slʌŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn pleɪs i kəd θɪŋk tə ɡoʊ fəɹ hɛlp ɪn ɹɛskjuɪŋ ɛɡwin.

Gawyn slung himself into his saddle. There was only one place he could think to go for help in rescuing Egwene.

wɪð ə kɪk ə ðə hilz, hi lɛf dɔɹlən bɪhaɪnd.

With a kick of the heels, he left Dorlan behind.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹtin

CHAPTER 14

eɪ bɑks oʊpənz "soʊ ðɪs ɪz wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld," sɔɹɪliə sɛd. ðə waɪt-hɛɹd waɪz wʌn sɝkəld ɝaʊn ðə pɹɪznɝ, lʊkɪŋ θɔtfəli ət sɛmɝhɪdʒ. ʌv kɔɹs, kædzueɪn hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd fɪɹ fɹəm wʌn sətʃ əz sɔɹɪliə. ði il wʊmən wɑz ə ɹʌɡəd kɹitʃɝ, laɪk ə stætʃu ðət hæd wɛðɝd stɔɹm æftɝ stɔɹm, peɪʃən bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪnz. əmʌŋ ði il, ðɪs waɪz wʌn wɑz ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ spɛsəmən ə stʃɹɛŋkθ.

A Box Opens "So this is one of the Shadowsouled," Sorilea said. The white-haired Wise One circled around the prisoner, looking thoughtfully at Semirhage. Of course, Cadsuane had not expected fear from one such as Sorilea. The Aiel woman was a rugged creature, like a statue that had weathered storm after storm, patient before the winds. Among the Aiel, this Wise One was a particular specimen of strength.

ʃi hæɾ ɝaɪvd ət ðə mænɝ haʊs oʊnli ɹisənli, kʌmɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz u hæd bɹɔɾ ælθɹ ə ɹipɔɹt fɹəm bændɑɹ ɛbən.

She had arrived at the manor house only recently, coming with those who had brought al'Thor a report from Bandar Eban.

kædzueɪn hæɾ æntɪsəpeɪɾəd faɪndɪŋ mɛni θɪŋz əmʌŋ ði il u fɑloʊd ɹænd ælθɹ: fɪɹs wɔɹiɝz, stʃɹeɪnʒ weɪz, ɑnɝ ən lɔɪəlti, ɪnɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð sʌɾəlti ən pɑlətɪks. ʃi hæd bɪn ɹaɪt.

Cadsuane had anticipated finding many things among the Aiel who followed Rand al'Thor: fierce warriors, strange ways, honor and loyalty, inexperience with subtlety and politics. She had been right.

wʌn θɪŋ ʃi hæd sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪnd, haʊɛvɝ, wɑz ən ikwəl. sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɪn ə waɪz wʌn u kəd bɛɹli tʃænəl. ən jɛt, ɑdli, ðət wɑz haʊ ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə lɛðɝi-feɪst il wʊmən.

One thing she had certainly not expected to find, however, was an equal. Certainly not in a Wise One who could barely channel. And yet, oddly, that was how she regarded the leathery-faced Aiel woman.

nɑt ðət ʃi tʃɹʌstɪd sɔɹɪliə. ðə waɪz wʌn hæɾ əɹ oʊn ɡoʊlz, ən ðeɪ maɪt nɑt kəmplitli koʊɪnsaɪd wɪð kædzueɪnz. haʊɛvɝ, ʃi dɪd faɪn sɔɹɪliə keɪpəbəl, ən ðəɹ wɝ blɛsɪd fju pipəl ɪn ðə wɝl ðiz deɪz u dɪzɝv ðət wɝd.

Not that she trusted Sorilea. The Wise One had her own goals, and they might not completely coincide with Cadsuane's. However, she did find Sorilea capable, and there were blessed few people in the world these days who deserved that word.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ flɪntʃt sʌɾənli, ən sɔɹɪliə kɑkt əɹ hɛd. ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑz nɑt floʊɾɪŋ ðɪs taɪm; ʃi stʊɾ əpɹaɪt, wɛɹɪŋ ðə stɪf bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs, hɝ ʃɔɹt, dɑɹk hɛɹ tæŋɡəl fɹəm læk ə bɹʌʃɪŋ. ʃi stɪl pɹədʒɛktəd supɪɹiɔɹɪɾi ən kəntʃɹoʊl. dʒʌst əz kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf wəɾ əv ɪn ə sɪməlɝ sɪtʃueɪʃən.

Semirhage flinched suddenly, and Sorilea cocked her head. The Forsaken was not floating this time; she stood upright, wearing the stiff brown dress, her short, dark hair tangled from lack of brushing. She still projected superiority and control. Just as Cadsuane herself would have in a similar situation.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ ðiz wivz?" sɔɹɪliə æskt, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ. ðə wivz ɪn kwɛstʃən wɝ ðə sɔɹs ə sɛmɝhɪdʒəz əkeɪʒənəl flɪntʃɪŋ.

"What are these weaves?" Sorilea asked, gesturing. The weaves in question were the source of Semirhage's occasional flinching.

"ə pɝsənəl tʃɹɪk ə maɪn," kædzueɪn sɛd, ənduɪŋ ðə wivz ən ɹimeɪkɪŋ əm tə ʃoʊ haʊ ðeɪ wɝ dʌn. "ðeɪ ɹɪŋ ə saʊn ɪn jəɹ sʌbʒɪkts' ɪɹz ɛvɹi fju mɪnəts ən flæʃ ə laɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, kipɪŋ əm fɹəm slip."

"A personal trick of mine," Cadsuane said, undoing the weaves and remaking them to show how they were done. "They ring a sound in your subjects' ears every few minutes and flash a light in their eyes, keeping them from sleep."

"ju hoʊp tə meɪk əɹ soʊ fətiɡd ðət ʃɪl tɔk," sɔɹɪliə sɛd, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə fɔɹseɪkən əɡɛn.

"You hope to make her so fatigued that she will talk," Sorilea said, studying the Forsaken again.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz wɔɹɾɪd tə kip əɹ fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ ðɛm, ʌv kɔɹs. dɪspaɪt tu deɪz wɪθaʊt disən slip, ðə wʊmən wɔɹ ə sɝin ɪkspɹɛʃən, aɪz oʊpən bʌt blɑk baɪ ɡloʊɪŋ laɪts. ʃi hæd laɪkli mæstɝd səm kaɪndə mɛntəl tʃɹɪk tə hɛlp əɹ steɪv ɔf ɪɡzɔstʃən.

Semirhage was warded to keep her from hearing them, of course. Despite two days without decent sleep, the woman wore a serene expression, eyes open but blocked by glowing lights. She had likely mastered some kind of mental trick to help her stave off exhaustion.

"aɪ daʊɾ ɪɾəl bɹeɪk hɝ," kædzueɪn ədmɪɾəd. "fɔ! ɪt bɛɹli ivən meɪks əɹ flɪntʃ." ʃi, sɔɹɪliə ən bɛɹ - ən eɪdʒɪd waɪz wʌn wɪð noʊ tʃænəlɪŋ əbɪləɾi - wɝ ði oʊnli wʌnz ɪn ðə ɹum.

"I doubt it will break her," Cadsuane admitted. "Phaw! It barely even makes her flinch." She, Sorilea and Bair - an aged Wise One with no channeling ability - were the only ones in the room.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪnteɪnɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒəz ʃil sæɾ ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪsəz aʊtsaɪd.

The Aes Sedai maintaining Semirhage's shield sat in their places outside.

sɔɹɪliə nɑɾəd. "wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld wɪl nɑt bi mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd soʊ izəli. stɪl, jə ɑɹ waɪz tə tʃɹaɪ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ jəɹ . . . lɪmɪteɪʃənz."

Sorilea nodded. "One of the Shadowsouled will not be manipulated so easily. Still, you are wise to try, considering your . . . limitations."

"wi kəd spik tə ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn," bɛɹ sɛd. "kənvɪns ɪm tə tɝn ðɪs wʌn oʊvɝ tə əs fəɹ ə taɪm. ə fju deɪz ʌv . . . dɛləkəɾ il kwɛstʃənɪŋ ən ʃi wəd spik wʌtɛvɝ jə wɪʃ."

"We could speak to the Car'a'carn," Bair said. "Convince him to turn this one over to us for a time. A few days of . . . delicate Aiel questioning and she would speak whatever you wish."

kædzueɪn smaɪl nɑnkəmɪɾəli. əz ɪf ʃi wəd lɛɾ ənʌðɝ hændəl ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ! ðɪs wʊmənz sikɹəts wɝ tu væljəbəl tə ɹɪsk, ivən ɪn ðə hænz ʌv ælaɪz. "wɛl, jə ɑɹ wɛlkəm tə æsk," ʃi sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ daʊɾ ælθɹ wɪl lɪsən. jə noʊ haʊ ðə ful bɔɪ kən bi wən ɪt kʌmz tə hɝɾɪŋ wɪmən."

Cadsuane smiled noncommittally. As if she would let another handle the questioning! This woman's secrets were too valuable to risk, even in the hands of allies. "Well, you are welcome to ask," she said, "but I doubt al'Thor will listen. You know how the fool boy can be when it comes to hurting women."

bɛɹ saɪd. ɪt wɑz ɑd tə θɪŋk ə ðɪs ɡɹændmʌðɝli leɪɾi ɛnɡeɪdʒɪŋ ɪn "dɛləkəɾ il kwɛstʃənɪŋ."

Bair sighed. It was odd to think of this grandmotherly lady engaging in "delicate Aiel questioning."

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd. "ju ɑɹ ɹaɪt, aɪ səspɛkt. ɹænd ælθɹ ɪz twaɪs əz stʌbɝn əz ɛni klæn tʃif aɪv noʊn. ən twaɪs əz ɛɹəɡən tu. tə pɹɪzum ðət wɪmən kænɑt bɛɹ peɪn əz wɛl əz mɛn!"

"Yes," she said. "You are right, I suspect. Rand al'Thor is twice as stubborn as any clan chief I've known. And twice as arrogant too. To presume that women cannot bear pain as well as men!"

kædzueɪn snɔɹɾɪd ət ðæt. "tə bi ɑnəst, aɪ kənsɪɾɝd hævɪŋ ðɪs wʌn stʃɹʌŋ ʌp ən wɪpt, ælθɹz pɹoʊəbɪʃənz bi blækənd! bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɪt wəd wɝk. fɔ! wɪl nid tə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən peɪn tə bɹeɪk ðɪs wʌn."

Cadsuane snorted at that. "To be honest, I considered having this one strung up and whipped, al'Thor's prohibitions be blackened! But I don't think it would work. Phaw! We'll need to find something other than pain to break this one."

sɔɹɪliə wɑz stɪl ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒ. "aɪ wəd spik wɪð hɝ."

Sorilea was still regarding Semirhage. "I would speak with her."

kædzueɪn meɪɾ ə moʊʃən, dɪsmɪsɪŋ ðə wivz ðət kɛp sɛmɝhɪdʒ fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ, siɪŋ əɹ spikɪŋ. ðə wʊmən blɪŋkt - dʒʌst wʌns - tə klɪɹ əɹ vɪʒən, ðən tɝn tə sɔɹɪliə ən bɛɹ. "ɑ,"

Cadsuane made a motion, dismissing the weaves that kept Semirhage from hearing, seeing or speaking. The woman blinked - just once - to clear her vision, then turned to Sorilea and Bair. "Ah,"

ʃi sɛd. "il. jə wɝ sətʃ ɡʊd sɝvəns, wʌns. tɛl mi, haʊ stʃɹɔŋli dʌz ɪt baɪt, noʊɪŋ haʊ jə bɪtʃɹeɪd jəɹ oʊðz? jəɹ ænsɛstɝz wəd kɹaɪ fəɹ pʌnɪʃmən ɪf ðeɪ nu haʊ mɛni dɛθs leɪ ət ðə hænz ə ðɛɹ dɪsɛndəns."

she said. "Aiel. You were such good servants, once. Tell me, how strongly does it bite, knowing how you betrayed your oaths? Your ancestors would cry for punishment if they knew how many deaths lay at the hands of their descendants."

sɔɹɪliə ɡeɪv noʊ ɹiækʃən. kædzueɪn nu səm tɪdbɪts ʌv wʌɾ ælθɹ hæd ɹɪvild əbaʊt ði il, θɪŋz ðət hæd bɪn sɛɾ ət sɛkən əɹ θɝd hænd. ælθɹ kleɪm ðət ði il hæd wʌns fɑloʊd ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif, swɔɹn nɑt tə də hɑɹm, bɪfɔɹ bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊðz. kædzueɪn hæd bɪn ɪntʃɹəstəd tə lɝn ə ðiz ɹumɝz, ən ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəd tə hɪɹ sɛmɝhɪdʒ kɝɑbɝeɪɾɪŋ ðɛm.

Sorilea gave no reaction. Cadsuane knew some tidbits of what al'Thor had revealed about the Aiel, things that had been said at second or third hand. Al'Thor claimed that the Aiel had once followed the Way of the Leaf, sworn not to do harm, before betraying their oaths. Cadsuane had been interested to learn of these rumors, and she was more interested to hear Semirhage corroborating them.

"ʃi simz soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ hjumən ðən aɪ hæɾ æntɪsəpeɪɾəd," sɔɹɪliə sɛd tə bɛɹ. "hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃənz, hɝ toʊn, hɝ æksɛnt, waɪl stʃɹeɪnʒ, ɑɹ izi tə ʌndɝstænd. aɪ hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðæt."

"She seems so much more human than I had anticipated," Sorilea said to Bair. "Her expressions, her tone, her accent, while strange, are easy to understand. I had not expected that."

sɛmɝhɪdʒəz aɪz nɛɹoʊd fəɹ dʒʌst ə moʊmən ət ðət kɑmɛnt. ɑd. ðət wɑz ə stʃɹɔŋɝ ɹiækʃən ðən vɝtʃuəli ɛni ʌv ðə pʌnɪʃməns hæd pɹədust. ðə flæʃɪz ə laɪɾ ən saʊn pɹɑmptəɾ oʊnli slaɪɾ ɪnvɑləntɛɹi twɪtʃɪz. ðɪs kɑmɛn ə sɔɹɪliəz, haʊɛvɝ, sim tə əfɛk sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɑn ən ɪmoʊʃənəl lɛvəl. wəd ðə waɪz wʌnz æktʃəli  səksid soʊ izəli wɛɹ kædzueɪn hæd lɔŋ feɪld?

Semirhage's eyes narrowed for just a moment at that comment. Odd. That was a stronger reaction than virtually any of the punishments had produced. The flashes of light and sound prompted only slight involuntary twitches. This comment of Sorilea's, however, seemed to affect Semirhage on an emotional level. Would the Wise Ones actually succeed so easily where Cadsuane had long failed?

"aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz wʌt wi nid tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ," bɛɹ sɛd. "ə wʊmən ɪz dʒʌst ə wʊmən, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ oʊld, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt sikɹəts ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝz. flɛʃ kən bi kʌt, blʌd kən bi spɪld, boʊnz kən bi bɹoʊkən."

"I think this is what we need to remember," Bair said. "A woman is just a woman, no matter how old, no matter what secrets she remembers. Flesh can be cut, blood can be spilled, bones can be broken."

"ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪ fil ɔlmoʊs dɪsəpɔɪntɪd, kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn," sɔɹɪliə sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ə waɪt-hɛɹd hɛd. "ðɪs mɑnstɝ əz vɛɹi smɔl fæŋz."

"In truth, I feel almost disappointed, Cadsuane Melaidhrin," Sorilea said, shaking a white-haired head. "This monster has very small fangs."

sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɹiæktəd noʊ fɝðɝ. hɝ kəntʃɹoʊl wɑz bæk, hɝ feɪs sɝin, hɝ aɪz ɪmpɪɹiəs. "aɪ hæv hɝd səm lɪɾəl ə jə nu, oʊθləs il ən jəɹ ɪntɝpɹɪteɪʃənz ʌv ɑnɝ. əl vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɛndʒɔɪ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ peɪn ən sʌfɝɪŋ ɪɾəl ɹikwaɪɝ bɪfɔɹ mɛmbɝz ə jəɹ klænz wɪl ʃeɪm ðɛmsɛlvz. tɛl mi, haʊ fɑɹ dʒju θɪŋk aɪ wəɾ əv tə pʊʃ bɪfɔɹ wʌn ə jə wəd kɪl ə blæksmɪθ ən daɪn ɑn ɪz flɛʃ?"

Semirhage reacted no further. Her control was back, her face serene, her eyes imperious. "I have heard some little of you new, oathless Aiel and your interpretations of honor. I will very much enjoy investigating how much pain and suffering it will require before members of your clans will shame themselves. Tell me, how far do you think I would have to push before one of you would kill a blacksmith and dine on his flesh?"

ʃi nu mɔɹ ðən "sʌm lɪɾəl" ɪf ʃi ʌndɝstʊd ðə nɪɹ-seɪkɹəd neɪtʃɝ ə blæksmɪθs əmʌŋ ði il. sɔɹɪliə stɪfən ət ðə kɑmɛnt, bʌt lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ. ʃi ɹɪwʌv ðə wɔɹɾ əɡɛns lɪsnɪŋ, ðən pɔzd, ən pleɪs ðə ɡlɑbz ə laɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə sɛmɝhɪdʒəz aɪz əz wɛl. jɛs, ʃi wɑz wik ɪn ðə paʊɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ə vɛɹi kwɪk lɝnɝ.

She knew more than "some little" if she understood the near-sacred nature of blacksmiths among the Aiel. Sorilea stiffened at the comment, but let it go. She rewove the ward against listening, then paused, and placed the globes of light in front of Semirhage's eyes as well. Yes, she was weak in the Power, but she was a very quick learner.

"ɪz ɪt waɪz tə kip əɹ laɪk ðɪs?" sɔɹɪliə æskt, hɝ toʊn ɪmplaɪɪŋ ðəɾ ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ ʃi wʊɾə meɪɾ ə dɪmænd. fəɹ kædzueɪn, ʃi sɔfən əɹ wɝdz, ən ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs bɹɔɾ ə smaɪl tə kædzueɪnz lɪps. ðeɪ wɝ laɪk tu eɪdʒ hɔks, sɔɹɪliə ən ʃi, əkʌstəm tə ɹustɪŋ ən ɹeɪnɪŋ, naʊ fɔɹs tə nɛst ɪn neɪbɝɪŋ tʃɹiz. dɛfɝəns dɪd nɑt kʌm izəli tə iðɝ wʌn ə ðɛm.

"Is it wise to keep her like this?" Sorilea asked, her tone implying that of any other she would have made a demand. For Cadsuane, she softened her words, and it almost brought a smile to Cadsuane's lips. They were like two aged hawks, Sorilea and she, accustomed to roosting and reigning, now forced to nest in neighboring trees. Deference did not come easily to either one of them.

"ɪf aɪ wɝ tə tʃuz," sɔɹɪliə kəntɪnjud, "aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪ wəɾ əv əɹ θɹoʊt slɪɾ ən əɹ kɔɹps leɪɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə dʌs tə dʒɹaɪ. kipɪŋ əɹ əlaɪv ɪz laɪk kipɪŋ ə snæpwʊd blækləns əz ə pɛt."

"If I were to choose," Sorilea continued, "I think that I would have her throat slit and her corpse laid out on the dust to dry. Keeping her alive is like keeping a snapwood blacklance as a pet."

"fɔ!" kædzueɪn sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "jɔɹ ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðə deɪnʒɝ, bʌt kɪlɪŋ əɹ naʊ wəd bi wɝs. ælθɹ kænɑt - əɹ wɪl nɑt - ɡɪmi ən ækjɝət kaʊn ə ðə nʌmbɝ ə fɔɹseɪkən hiz sleɪn, bʌɾ i ɪmplaɪz ðəɾ ət lis hæf ə ðɛm stɪl laɪv. ðəl bi ðəɹ tə faɪɾ ət ðə læs bæɾəl, ən itʃ wiv wi lɝn fɹəm sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɪz wʌn fjuɝ ðeɪ kən juz tə sɝpɹaɪz ʌs."

"Phaw!" Cadsuane said, grimacing. "You're right about the danger, but killing her now would be worse. Al'Thor cannot - or will not - give me an accurate count of the number of Forsaken he has slain, but he implies that at least half of them still live. They'll be there to fight at the Last Battle, and each weave we learn from Semirhage is one fewer they can use to surprise us."

sɔɹɪliə dɪd nɑt sim kənvɪnst, bʌt ʃi pɹɛs ði ɪʃu noʊ fɝðɝ. "æn ði aɪɾəm?" ʃi æskt.

Sorilea did not seem convinced, but she pressed the issue no further. "And the item?" she asked.

"meɪ aɪ si ɪt?"

"May I see it?"

kædzueɪn ɔlmoʊst snæpt ə noʊ. bʌt . . . sɔɹɪliə hæd tɔt kædzueɪn tʃɹævlɪŋ, ən ɪnkɹɛɾəbli paʊɝfəl tul. ðət hæd bɪn ən ɔfɝɪŋ, ə hæn ɪkstɛndəd. kædzueɪn niɾəd tə wɝk wɪð ðiz wɪmən, sɔɹɪliə moʊst ʌv ɔl. ælθɹ wɑz ə bɪɡɝ pɹɑdʒɛk ðən wʌn wʊmən kəd hændəl.

Cadsuane almost snapped a no. But . . . Sorilea had taught Cadsuane Traveling, an incredibly powerful tool. That had been an offering, a hand extended. Cadsuane needed to work with these women, Sorilea most of all. Al'Thor was a bigger project than one woman could handle.

"kʌm wɪð mi," kædzueɪn sɛd, livɪŋ ðə wʊɾən ɹum. ðə waɪz wʌnz fɑloʊd. aʊtsaɪd, kædzueɪn ɪnstʃɹʌktəd ðə sɪstɝz - deɪdʒiən ən sɝin - tə meɪk sɝɾən ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz kɛpt əweɪk, aɪz oʊpən. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli tə wɝk, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə bɛst stʃɹæɾədʒi kædzueɪn hæɾ ət ðə moʊmənt.

"Come with me," Cadsuane said, leaving the wooden room. The Wise Ones followed. Outside, Cadsuane instructed the sisters - Daigian and Sarene - to make certain that Semirhage was kept awake, eyes open. It was unlikely to work, but it was the best strategy Cadsuane had at the moment.

ðoʊ . . . ʃi dɪɾ ɔlsoʊ hæv sɛmɝhɪdʒəz moʊməntɛɹi lʊk, ðət hɪn ʌv æŋɡɝ, dɪspleɪɾ ət sɔɹɪliəz kɑmɛnt. wən jə kəd kəntʃɹoʊl ə pɝsənz æŋɡɝ, jə kəd kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛɹ ʌðɝ ɪmoʊʃənz əz wɛl. ðət wɑz waɪ ʃi hæd foʊkəst soʊ hɑɹɾ ɑn titʃɪŋ ælθɹ tə ɹeɪn ɪn ɪz tɛmpɝ.

Though . . . she did also have Semirhage's momentary look, that hint of anger, displayed at Sorilea's comment. When you could control a person's anger, you could control their other emotions as well. That was why she had focused so hard on teaching al'Thor to rein in his temper.

kəntʃɹoʊl ən æŋɡɝ. wʌt wɑz ɪt ðət sɔɹɪliə hæd sɛd tə ɡɛt ðə ɹiækʃən? ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ sim dɪsəpɔɪntɪŋli hjumən. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf sɔɹɪliə hæd kʌm ɪkspɛktɪŋ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən tə bi əz twɪstəɾ əz ə mɹdʒɹɑl əɹ dʒɹæɡkɝ. ən waɪ nɑt? ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd bɪn fɪɡjɝz ə lɛdʒən fəɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz, lumɪŋ ʃædoʊz ə dɑɹknəs ən mɪstɝi. ɪt kəd bi dɪsəpɔɪntɪŋ tə dɪskʌvɝ ðət ðeɪ wɝ, ɪn mɛni weɪz, ðə moʊs hjumən ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz fɑloʊɝz: pɛɾi, dɪstʃɹʌktɪv ən ɑɹɡjəmɛntəɾɪv. ət list, ðət wɑz haʊ ælθɹ kleɪm ðeɪ æktəd. hi wɑz soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒli fəmɪljɝ wɪð ðɛm.

Control and anger. What was it that Sorilea had said to get the reaction? That Semirhage seemed disappointingly human. It was as if Sorilea had come expecting one of the Forsaken to be as twisted as a Myrddraal or Draghkar. And why not? The Forsaken had been figures of legend for three thousand years, looming shadows of darkness and mystery. It could be disappointing to discover that they were, in many ways, the most human of the Dark One's followers: petty, destructive and argumentative. At least, that was how al'Thor claimed they acted. He was so strangely familiar with them.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɔ hɝsɛlf əz mɔɹ ðən hjumən, ðoʊ. ðət pɔɪz, ðət kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝ sɝaʊndɪŋz, wɑz ə sɔɹs ə stʃɹɛŋkθ fəɹ hɝ.

Semirhage saw herself as more than human, though. That poise, that control of her surroundings, was a source of strength for her.

kædzueɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. tu mɛni pɹɑbləmz ən fɑɹ tu lɪɾəl taɪm. ðə wʊɾən hɔlweɪ ɪtsɛlf wɑz ənʌðɝ ɹimaɪndɝ ə ði ælθɹ bɔɪz fulɪʃnəs; kædzueɪn kəd stɪl smɛl smoʊk, stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bi ənplɛzənt. ðə ɡeɪpɪŋ hoʊl ɪn ðə fɹʌn ə ðə mænɝ - dʒɹeɪpt oʊnli wɪð ə klɔθ - lɛɾ ɪn tʃɪl ɛɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə spɹɪŋ naɪts. ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv muvd, bʌɾ i kleɪm ðəɾ i wəd nɑt bi tʃeɪst əweɪ.

Cadsuane shook her head. Too many problems and far too little time. The wooden hallway itself was another reminder of the al'Thor boy's foolishness; Cadsuane could still smell smoke, strong enough to be unpleasant. The gaping hole in the front of the manor - draped only with a cloth - let in chill air during the spring nights. They should have moved, but he claimed that he would not be chased away.

ælθɹ simd ɔlmoʊst iɡɝ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. əɹ pɝhæps dʒʌst ɹɪzaɪnd. tə ɡɛt ðəɹ i fɛlt i hæd tə fɔɹs ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə pɛɾi skwɑbəlz ə pipəl laɪk ə mɪdnaɪt tʃɹævəlɝ pʊʃɪŋ θɹu bæŋks ə snoʊ tə ɝaɪv ət ði ɪn. ðə pɹɑbləm wɑz, ælθɹ wɑzn ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

Al'Thor seemed almost eager for the Last Battle. Or perhaps just resigned. To get there he felt he had to force his way through the petty squabbles of people like a midnight traveler pushing through banks of snow to arrive at the inn. The problem was, al'Thor wasn't ready for the Last Battle.

kædzueɪn kəd fil ɪɾ ɪn ðə weɪ hi spoʊk, ðə weɪ hi æktəd. ðə weɪ hi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə wɝld wɪð ðət dɑɹk, nɪɹli deɪzd ɪkspɹɛʃən. ɪf ðə mæn i wɑz naʊ feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn tə dɪsaɪd ðə feɪɾ ə ðə wɝld, kædzueɪn fɪɹd fəɹ ɔl pipəl.

Cadsuane could feel it in the way he spoke, the way he acted. The way he regarded the world with that dark, nearly dazed expression. If the man he was now faced the Dark One to decide the fate of the world, Cadsuane feared for all people.

kædzueɪn ən ðə tu waɪz wʌnz ɹitʃt əɹ tʃeɪmbɝ ɪn ðə mænɝ, ə stɝɾi ʌndæmədʒd ɹum wɪð ə ɡʊd vju ʌv ðə tʃɹæmpəld ɡɹin ən kæmp aʊt fɹʌnt. ʃi meɪd fju dɪmænz ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv dɛkɝeɪʃən: ə staʊt bɛd, ə lɑkəbəl tʃɹʌŋk, ə mɪɹɝ ən stænd. ʃi wɑz tu oʊld ən ɪmpeɪʃən tə bɑðɝ wɪð ɛniθɪŋ ɛls.

Cadsuane and the two Wise Ones reached her chamber in the manor, a sturdy undamaged room with a good view of the trampled green and camp out front. She made few demands in the way of decoration: a stout bed, a lockable trunk, a mirror and stand. She was too old and impatient to bother with anything else.

ðə tʃɹʌŋk wɑz ə dəkɔɪ; ʃi kɛp səm ɡoʊld ən ʌðɝ ɹɛləɾɪvli wɝθləs aɪɾəmz ɪn ɪt. hɝ moʊs pɹɛʃəs pəzɛʃənz ʃi iðɝ wɔɹ - ɪn ðə fɔɹm ə hɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɔɹnəməns - əɹ kɛp lɑkt ɪn ə dɪnʒi-lʊkɪŋ dɑkjəmɛn bɑks ðət sæɾ ɑn əɹ mɪɹɝ stænd. ʌv wɔɹn oʊk, ðə steɪn ənivən, ðə bɑks hæɾ ɪnʌf dɪŋz ən dɛns tə lʊk juzd - bʌt wɑzn soʊ ʃæbi əz tə bi aʊɾ ə pleɪs wɪð əɹ ʌðɝ θɪŋz.

The trunk was a decoy; she kept some gold and other relatively worthless items in it. Her most precious possessions she either wore - in the form of her ter'angreal ornaments - or kept locked in a dingy-looking document box that sat on her mirror stand. Of worn oak, the stain uneven, the box had enough dings and dents to look used - but wasn't so shabby as to be out of place with her other things.

əz sɔɹɪliə kloʊz ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm, kædzueɪn dɪsɑɹm ðə bɑksəz tʃɹæps.

As Sorilea closed the door behind the three of them, Cadsuane disarmed the box's traps.

ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ tə hɝ haʊ fju ɛɛs sədaɪ lɝn tə ɪnəveɪt wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðeɪ mɛmɝaɪz taɪm-tɛstəɾ ən tʃɹədɪʃənəl wivz, bʌt ɡeɪv bɛɹli ə θɔt fəɹ wʌɾ ɛls ðeɪ kəd du.

It was strange to her how few Aes Sedai learned to innovate with the One Power. They memorized time-tested and traditional weaves, but gave barely a thought for what else they could do.

tʃɹu, ɛkspɛɹəmɛntɪŋ wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ kəd bi dɪzæstʃɹəs, bʌt mɛni sɪmpəl ɪkstʃɹæpəleɪʃənz kəd bi meɪd wɪθaʊt deɪnʒɝ. hɝ wiv fəɹ ðɪs bɑks wɑz wʌn sʌtʃ. əntɪl ɹisənli, ʃid juzd ə stændɝd wiv ə faɪɝ, spɪɹəɾ ən ɛɹ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɛni dɑkjəməns ɪn ðə bɑks ɪf ən ɪntʃɹuɾɝ oʊpən ɪt. ɪfɛktɪv, ɪf ə bɪɾ ənɪmædʒɪnəɾɪv.

True, experimenting with the One Power could be disastrous, but many simple extrapolations could be made without danger. Her weave for this box was one such. Until recently, she'd used a standard weave of Fire, Spirit and Air to destroy any documents in the box if an intruder opened it. Effective, if a bit unimaginative.

hɝ nu wiv wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ vɝsəɾəl. ɪt dɪdn dɪstʃɹɔɪ ði aɪɾəmz ɪn ðə bɑks - kædzueɪn wɑzn sɝɾən ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd. ɪnstɛd, ðə wivz - ɪnvɝɾɪd tə bi ɪnvɪzəbəl - spɹæŋ aʊɾ ɪn twɪstɪŋ θɹɛdz ʌv ɛɹ ən kæptʃɝɾ ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə ɹum wən ðə bɑks wɑz oʊpənd. ðən ənʌðɝ wiv sɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɑɹdʒ saʊnd, ɪməteɪɾɪŋ ə hʌnʒɹəd tʃɹʌmpəts pleɪɪŋ waɪl laɪts flæʃt ɪn ði ɛɹ tə ɡɪv ði əlɑɹm. ðə wivz wəɾ ɔlsoʊ ɡoʊ ɔf ɪf ɛniwʌn oʊpən ðə bɑks, muvd ɪt, əɹ bɛɹli tʌtʃt ɪt wɪð ðə moʊs dɛləkət θɹɛɾ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

Her new weave was much more versatile. It didn't destroy the items in the box - Cadsuane wasn't certain if they could be destroyed. Instead, the weaves - inverted to be invisible - sprang out in twisting threads of Air and captured anyone in the room when the box was opened. Then another weave set out a large sound, imitating a hundred trumpets playing while lights flashed in the air to give the alarm. The weaves would also go off if anyone opened the box, moved it, or barely touched it with the most delicate thread of the One Power.

kædzueɪn flɪpt ʌp ðə lɪd. ði ɪkstʃɹim pɹikɔʃən wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. fəɹ ɪnsaɪd ðɪs bɑks wɝ tu aɪɾəmz ðət pɹizɛntəd vɛɹi sɪɹiəs deɪnʒɝ.

Cadsuane flipped up the lid. The extreme precaution was necessary. For inside this box were two items that presented very serious danger.

sɔɹɪliə wɔkt oʊvɝ, lʊkɪŋ ɪn ət ðə kɑntɛns. wʌn wɑz ə fɪɡjɝin ʌv ə waɪz, bɪɹɾəd mæn hoʊldɪŋ əlɔft ə sfɪɹ, əbaʊɾ ə fʊt tɔl. ði ʌðɝ wɑz ə blæk mətælɪk kɑlɝ ən tu bɹeɪslɪts: ən æɾəm meɪd fəɹ ə mæn. wɪð ðɪs tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ə wʊmən kəd tɝn ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl ɪndə hɝ sleɪv, kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɪz əbɪləɾi tə tʌtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. pɝhæps kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɪm kəmplitli. ðeɪ hæd nɑt tɛstəd ðə kɑlɝ. ælθɹ hæd fɔɹbɪɾən ɪt.

Sorilea walked over, looking in at the contents. One was a figurine of a wise, bearded man holding aloft a sphere, about a foot tall. The other was a black metallic collar and two bracelets: an a'dam made for a man. With this ter'angreal, a woman could turn a man who could channel into her slave, controlling his ability to touch the One Power. Perhaps controlling him completely. They had not tested the collar. Al'Thor had forbidden it.

sɔɹɪliə hɪs kwaɪətli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə stætʃu ən foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ðə bɹeɪslɪts ən kɑlɝ. "ðɪs θɪŋ ɪz ivəl."

Sorilea hissed quietly, ignoring the statue and focusing on the bracelets and collar. "This thing is evil."

"jɛs," kædzueɪn sɛd. ɹɛɹli wəd ʃi hæv kɔld ə sɪmpəl ɑbʒɛkt "ivəl," bʌt ðɪs wʌn wɑz.

"Yes," Cadsuane said. Rarely would she have called a simple object "evil," but this one was.

"nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə kleɪmz səm fəmɪljɛɹəɾi wɪð ðɪs θɪŋ. ðoʊ aɪ hæv nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə pɹɛs aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɝl haʊ ʃi noʊz ðiz θɪŋz, ʃi kleɪmz tə noʊ ðət ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn meɪl æɾəm, ən ðət ʃiɾ ɝeɪnʒd fəɹ ɪts dɪspoʊzəl ɪn ði oʊʃən. ʃi ɔlsoʊ ədmɪts, haʊɛvɝ, ðət ʃi dɪdn si ɪt dɪstʃɹɔɪd pɝsənəli. ɪt meɪ hæv bɪn juzd əz ə pæɾɝn baɪ ðə sintʃæn."

"Nynaeve al'Meara claims some familiarity with this thing. Though I have not been able to press out of the girl how she knows these things, she claims to know that there was only one male a'dam, and that she'd arranged for its disposal in the ocean. She also admits, however, that she didn't see it destroyed personally. It may have been used as a pattern by the Seanchan."

"ðɪs ɪz ənsɛɾəlɪŋ tə si," sɔɹɪliə sɛd. "ɪf wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld, əɹ ivən wʌn ə ðə sintʃæn, kæptʃɝɾ ɪm wɪð ðɪs. . . ."

"This is unsettling to see," Sorilea said. "If one of the Shadowsouled, or even one of the Seanchan, captured him with this. . . ."

"laɪt pɹətɛkt əs ɔl," bɛɹ wɪspɝd.

"Light protect us all," Bair whispered.

"æn ðə pipəl u hæv ðiz ɑɹ ðə seɪm pipəl wɪð hum ælθɹ wɪʃɪz tə meɪk pis?"

"And the people who have these are the same people with whom al'Thor wishes to make peace?"

sɔɹɪliə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "kɹieɪʃən ə ðiz əbɑməneɪʃənz əloʊn ʃəd wɔɹən ə blʌd fjud. aɪ hɝd ðət ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz laɪk ɪt. wʌɾ ə ðoʊz?"

Sorilea shook her head. "Creation of these abominations alone should warrant a blood feud. I heard that there were others like it. What of those?"

"stɔɹɾ ɛlswɛɹ," kædzueɪn sɛd, ʃʌɾɪŋ ðə lɪd. "əlɔŋ wɪð ðə fimeɪl æɾəm wi tʊk.

"Stored elsewhere," Cadsuane said, shutting the lid. "Along with the female a'dam we took.

səm əkweɪntənsɪz ə maɪn - ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæv ɹɪtaɪɹd fɹəm ðə wɝld - ɑɹ tɛstɪŋ əm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪskʌvɝ ðɛɹ wiknəs." ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ hæd kælændɝ. kædzueɪn wɑz loʊθ tə lɛɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪt, bʌt ʃi fɛl ðət ðə sɔɹd stɪl hɛl sikɹəts ðət kəd bi tizd aʊt.

Some acquaintances of mine - Aes Sedai who have retired from the world - are testing them trying to discover their weakness." They also had Callandor. Cadsuane was loath to let it out of her sight, but she felt that the sword still held secrets that could be teased out.

"aɪ kip ðɪs wʌn hɪɹ kəz aɪ ɪntɛn tə faɪn ə weɪ tə tɛst ɪɾ ɑn ə mæn," ʃi sɛd. "ðæt wəd bi ðə bɛst weɪ tə dɪskʌvɝ ɪts wiknəsəz. ælθɹ woʊn əlaʊ ɛni ʌv ɪz æʃəmən tə bi liʃt baɪ ɪt, haʊɛvɝ. nɑt fəɹ ðə ʃɔɹɾɪst taɪm."

"I keep this one here because I intend to find a way to test it on a man," she said. "That would be the best way to discover its weaknesses. Al'Thor won't allow any of his Asha'man to be leashed by it, however. Not for the shortest time."

ðɪs meɪd bɛɹ ənkʌmftəɹbəl. "ə lɪɾəl laɪk tɛstɪŋ ə spɪɹz stʃɹɛŋkθ baɪ stæbɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə sʌmwʌn," ʃi mʌɾɝd.

This made Bair uncomfortable. "A little like testing a spear's strength by stabbing it into someone," she muttered.

sɔɹɪliə, haʊɛvɝ, nɑɾəd ɪn əɡɹimənt. ʃi ʌndɝstʊd.

Sorilea, however, nodded in agreement. She understood.

wʌn ə ðə fɝs θɪŋz kædzueɪn hæd dʌn æftɝ kæptʃɝɪŋ ðoʊz fimeɪl æɾəm wɑz pʊt wʌn ɑn ən pɹæktəs weɪz tə ɪskeɪp fɹəm ɪt. ʃid dʌn soʊ ʌndɝ kɛɹfəli kəntʃɹoʊl sɝkəmstænsəz, ʌv kɔɹs, wɪð wɪmən ʃi tʃɹʌstɪd tə hɛlp əɹ ɪskeɪp. ðeɪɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli hæd tə də ðæt. kædzueɪn hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə dɪskʌvɝ noʊ weɪ aʊɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn.

One of the first things Cadsuane had done after capturing those female a'dam was put one on and practice ways to escape from it. She'd done so under carefully controlled circumstances, of course, with women she trusted to help her escape. They'd eventually had to do that. Cadsuane had been able to discover no way out on her own.

bʌɾ ɪf jəɹ ɛnəmi wɑz plænɪŋ tə də sʌmθɪŋ tə ju, jə hæd tə dɪskʌvɝ haʊ tə kaʊntɝ ɪt.

But if your enemy was planning to do something to you, you had to discover how to counter it.

ivən ɪf ðət mɛn liʃɪŋ jɝsɛlf. ælθɹ kʊdn si ðɪs. wən ʃi æskt, hi sɪmpli mʌɾɝd əbaʊt "ðæt blʌɾi bɑks" ən biɪŋ biɾən.

Even if that meant leashing yourself. Al'Thor couldn't see this. When she asked, he simply muttered about "that bloody box" and being beaten.

"wi hæv tə də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðət mæn," sɔɹɪliə sɛd, miɾɪŋ kædzueɪnz aɪz. "hi hæz ɡɹoʊn wɝs sɪns wi læs mɛt."

"We have to do something about that man," Sorilea said, meeting Cadsuane's eyes. "He has grown worse since we last met."

"hi hæz," kædzueɪn sɛd. "hiz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli əkɑmplɪʃt əɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ maɪ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ."

"He has," Cadsuane said. "He's surprisingly accomplished at ignoring my training."

"ðɛn lɛɾ əs dɪskʌs," sɔɹɪliə sɛd, pʊlɪŋ oʊvɝ ə stul. "ə plæn mʌs bi ɝeɪnʒd. fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv ɔl."

"Then let us discuss," Sorilea said, pulling over a stool. "A plan must be arranged. For the good of all."

"fɔɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv ɔl," kædzueɪn əɡɹid. "ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf moʊst ʌv ɔl."

"For the good of all," Cadsuane agreed. "Al'Thor himself most of all."

tʃæptɝ fɪftin

CHAPTER 15

eɪ pleɪs tə bɪɡɪn ɹænd woʊk ɑn ðə flɔɹ ʌv ə hɔlweɪ. hi sæɾ ʌp, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə dɪstən saʊn ʌv wɔɾɝ. ðə stʃɹim aʊtsaɪd ðə mænɝ haʊs? noʊ . . . noʊ, ðət wɑz ɹɔŋ. ðə wɔlz ən flɔɹ hɪɹ wɝ stoʊn, nɑt wʊd.

A Place to Begin Rand woke on the floor of a hallway. He sat up, listening to the distant sound of water. The stream outside the manor house? No . . . no, that was wrong. The walls and floor here were stone, not wood.

noʊ kændəlz əɹ læmps hʌŋ fɹəm ðə stoʊnwɝk, ən jɛt ðəɹ wɑz laɪt, æmbiən ɪn ði ɛɹ.

No candles or lamps hung from the stonework, and yet there was light, ambient in the air.

hi stʊd, ðən stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪz ɹɛd koʊt, filɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒli ʌnəfɹeɪd. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɪs pleɪs fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ, dɪstən ɪn ɪz mɛmɹi. haʊ hæɾ i kʌm hɪɹ? ðə ɹisən pæst wɑz klaʊɾəd, ən sim tə slɪp fɹəm hɪm, laɪk feɪɾɪŋ tʃɹeɪlz ə mɪst. . . .

He stood, then straightened his red coat, feeling strangely unafraid. He recognized this place from somewhere, distant in his memory. How had he come here? The recent past was clouded, and seemed to slip from him, like fading trails of mist. . . .

noʊ, hi θɔt fɝmli. hɪz mɛmɹiz oʊbeɪd, snæpɪŋ bæk ɪndə pleɪs bɪfɔɹ ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə hɪz dɪtɝməneɪʃən. hi hæd bɪn ɪn ðə dəmɑni mænɝ haʊs, əweɪɾɪŋ ə ɹipɔɹt fɹəm ɹəɑɹk əbaʊt ðə kæptʃɝ ə ðə fɝs fju mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl. mɪn hæd bɪn ɹiɾɪŋ itʃ kæsəl, ə baɪɑɡɹəfi, ɪn ðə dip, ɡɹin tʃɛɹ ə ðə ɹum ðeɪ ʃɛɹd.

No, he thought firmly. His memories obeyed, snapping back into place before the strength of his determination. He had been in the Domani manor house, awaiting a report from Rhuarc about the capture of the first few members of the merchant council. Min had been reading Each Castle, a biography, in the deep, green chair of the room they shared.

ɹænd hæd bɪn ɪɡzɔstəd, əz i ɔfən wɑz leɪtli. hid ɡɔn tə laɪ daʊn. hi wɑz əslip, ðɛn.

Rand had been exhausted, as he often was lately. He'd gone to lie down. He was asleep, then.

wɑz ðɪs ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz? ðoʊ hi hæd vɪzəɾəd ɪɾ ɑn əkeɪʒən, hi nu vɛɹi fju spɪsɪfɪks.

Was this the World of Dreams? Though he had visited it on occasion, he knew very few specifics.

ɛɡwin ən ði il dʒɹimwɔkɝz spoʊk ʌv ɪɾ oʊnli ɡɑɹɾɪdli.

Egwene and the Aiel dreamwalkers spoke of it only guardedly.

ðɪs pleɪs fɛl dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə dʒɹim wɝld, ən ɑdli fəmɪljɝ. hi lʊk daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ;

This place felt different from the dream world, and oddly familiar. He looked down the hallway;

ɪt wɑz soʊ lɔŋ ðəɾ ɪt vænɪʃt ɪndə ʃædoʊz, wɔlz bɹoʊkən baɪ dɔɹz əɾ ɪntɝvəlz, ðə wʊd dʒɹaɪ ən kɹækt. jɛs . . . hi θɔt, sizɪŋ əɾ ə mɛmɹi. aɪ hæv bɪn hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ, bʌt nɑɾ ɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm.

it was so long that it vanished into shadows, walls broken by doors at intervals, the wood dry and cracked. Yes . . . he thought, seizing at a memory. I have been here before, but not in a long time.

hi tʃoʊz wʌn ə ðə dɔɹz ət ɹændəm - hi nu ðəɾ ɪt wʊdn mæɾɝ wɪtʃ wʌn i pɪkt - ən pʊʃt ɪɾ oʊpən. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹum bɪɑnd, ʌv mɑɾəst saɪz. ðə fɑɹ saɪd wɑz ə sɪɹiz ʌv ɡɹeɪ stoʊn ɑɹtʃəz, bɪɑn əm ə lɪɾəl kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ən ə skaɪ ʌv bɝnɪŋ ɹɛd klaʊdz. ðə klaʊdz ɡɹu ən spɹæŋ fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝ laɪk bʌbəlz ɪn bɔɪlɪŋ wɔɾɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ðə klaʊdz ʌv ən ɪmpɛndɪŋ stɔɹm, ənnætʃɹəl ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ.

He chose one of the doors at random - he knew that it wouldn't matter which one he picked - and pushed it open. There was a room beyond, of modest size. The far side was a series of gray stone arches, beyond them a little courtyard and a sky of burning red clouds. The clouds grew and sprang from one another like bubbles in boiling water. They were the clouds of an impending storm, unnatural though they were.

hi lʊk mɔɹ kloʊsli, ən sɔ ðəɾ itʃ nu klaʊd fɔɹm ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tɔɹmɛntɪd feɪs, ðə maʊθ oʊpən ɪn ə saɪlən skɹim. ðə klaʊd wəd swɛl, ɪkspændɪŋ əpɑn ɪtsɛlf, feɪs dɪstɔɹɾɪŋ, dʒɔ wɝkɪŋ, tʃiks twɪstɪŋ, aɪz bʌlʒɪŋ. ðən ɪt wəd splɪt, ʌðɝ feɪsəz swɛlɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɪts sɝfəs, jɛlɪŋ ən siθɪŋ. ɪt wɑz tʃɹænsfaɪksɪŋ ən hɔɹəfaɪɪŋ ət ðə seɪm taɪm.

He looked more closely, and saw that each new cloud formed the shape of a tormented face, the mouth open in a silent scream. The cloud would swell, expanding upon itself, face distorting, jaw working, cheeks twisting, eyes bulging. Then it would split, other faces swelling out of its surface, yelling and seething. It was transfixing and horrifying at the same time.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡɹaʊn bɪɑn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. dʒʌs ðət tɛɹəbəl skaɪ.

There was no ground beyond the courtyard. Just that terrible sky.

ɹænd dɪd nɑt wɑnə lʊk təwɔɹd ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum. ðə faɪɝpleɪs wɑz ðɛɹ. ðə stoʊnz ðət fɔɹm flɔɹ, hɑɹθ ən kɑləmz wɝ wɔɹpt, əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn mɛltəd baɪ ən ɪkstʃɹim hit. ət ði ɛdʒəz ə hɪz vɪʒən, ðeɪ sim tə ʃɪft ən tʃeɪnʒ. ði æŋɡəlz ən pɹəpɔɹʃənz ə ðə ɹum wɝ ɹɔŋ. dʒʌst əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn wən hid kʌm hɪɹ, lɔŋ əɡoʊ.

Rand did not want to look toward the left side of the room. The fireplace was there. The stones that formed floor, hearth and columns were warped, as if they had been melted by an extreme heat. At the edges of his vision, they seemed to shift and change. The angles and proportions of the room were wrong. Just as they had been when he'd come here, long ago.

sʌmθɪŋ wɑz dɪfɹən ðɪs taɪm, haʊɛvɝ. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kʌlɝz. mɛni ʌv ðə stoʊnz wɝ blæk, əz ɪf ðeɪd bɪn bɝnd, ən kɹæks leɪs ðɛm. dɪstən ɹɛd laɪt ɡloʊd fɹəm wɪðɪn, əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd kɔɹz ə moʊltən lɑvə. ðəɹ hæd wʌns bɪn ə teɪbəl hɪɹ, hædn ðɛɹ? pɑlɪʃt ən ə faɪn wʊd, ɪts ɔɹɾənɛɹi laɪnz ə dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋ kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə dɪstɔɹɾəd æŋɡəlz ə ðə stoʊnz?

Something was different this time, however. Something about the colors. Many of the stones were black, as if they'd been burned, and cracks laced them. Distant red light glowed from within, as if they had cores of molten lava. There had once been a table here, hadn't there? Polished and of fine wood, its ordinary lines a discomforting contrast to the distorted angles of the stones?

ðə teɪbəl wɑz ɡɔn, bʌt tu tʃɛɹz sæt bɪfɔɹ ðə faɪɝpleɪs, haɪ bækt ən feɪsɪŋ ðə fleɪmz, əbskjʊɹɪŋ humɛvɝ maɪt bi sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðɛm. ɹænd fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə wɔk fɔɹwɝd, hɪz buts klɪkɪŋ ɑn stoʊnz ðət bɝnd. hi fɛl noʊ hit, iðɝ fɹəm əm əɹ ðə faɪɝ. hɪz bɹɛθ kɑɾ ən ɪz hɑɹt paʊndɪɾ əz i əpɹoʊtʃt ðoʊz tʃɛɹz. hi fɪɹd wʌɾ i wəd faɪnd.

The table was gone, but two chairs sat before the fireplace, high backed and facing the flames, obscuring whomever might be sitting in them. Rand forced himself to walk forward, his boots clicking on stones that burned. He felt no heat, either from them or the fire. His breath caught and his heart pounded as he approached those chairs. He feared what he would find.

hi ɹaʊndəd ðɛm. ə mæn sæɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ ɑn ðə lɛft. tɔl ən juθfəl, hi hæɾ ə skwɛɹ feɪs ən eɪntʃən blu aɪz ðət ɹəflɛktəd ðə hɑɹθfaɪɝ, tɝnɪŋ ɪz aɪɹəsɪz ɔlmoʊs pɝpəl. ði ʌðɝ tʃɛɹ wɑz ɛmpti. ɹænd wɔk tə ɪɾ ən sæt daʊn, kɑmɪŋ ɪz hɑɹɾ ən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə dænsɪŋ fleɪmz. hi hæd sin ðɪs mæn bɪfɔɹ ɪn vɪʒənz, nɑɾ ənlaɪk ðə wʌnz ðəɾ əpɪɹd wən i θɔɾ ə mæt əɹ pɛɹɪn.

He rounded them. A man sat in the chair on the left. Tall and youthful, he had a square face and ancient blue eyes that reflected the hearthfire, turning his irises almost purple. The other chair was empty. Rand walked to it and sat down, calming his heart and watching the dancing flames. He had seen this man before in visions, not unlike the ones that appeared when he thought of Mat or Perrin.

ðə kʌlɝz dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ ɑn ðɪs θɔɾ ə hɪz fɹɛnz. ðət wɑz ɑd, bʌt sʌmhaʊ nɑɾ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd. ðə vɪʒənz hid sin ə ðə mæn ɪn ði ʌðɝ tʃɛɹ wɝ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə wʌnz ɪnvɑlvɪŋ pɛɹɪn ən mæt. ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ vɪsɝəl, sʌmhaʊ, mɔɹ ɹil. ət taɪmz dʊɹɪŋ ðoʊz vɪʒənz, ɹænd hæd fɛlt ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i kəd ɹitʃ aʊɾ ən tʌtʃ ðɪs mæn. hid bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ʌv wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf i dɪd.

The colors did not appear on this thought of his friends. That was odd, but somehow not unexpected. The visions he'd seen of the man in the other chair were different from the ones involving Perrin and Mat. They were more visceral, somehow, more real. At times during those visions, Rand had felt almost as if he could reach out and touch this man. He'd been afraid of what would happen if he did.

hi hæd mɛt ðə mæn oʊnli wʌns. ət ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ hæd seɪvd ɹændz laɪf, ən ɹænd hæɾ ɔfən wʌndɝɾ u hi hæd bɪn. naʊ, ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, ɹænd faɪnəli nu.

He had met the man only once. At Shadar Logoth. The stranger had saved Rand's life, and Rand had often wondered who he had been. Now, in this place, Rand finally knew.

"ju ɑɹ dɛd," ɹænd wɪspɝd. "aɪ kɪl ju."

"You are dead," Rand whispered. "I killed you."

ðə mæn dɪdn lʊk fɹəm ðə faɪɝ əz i læft. ɪt wɑz ə ɹʌf, loʊ-θɹoʊɾɪd læf ðət hɛld lɪɾəl tʃɹu mɝθ. wʌns, ɹænd hæd noʊn ðɪs mæn oʊnli əz bælzəmən - ə neɪm fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn - ən hæd fulɪʃli θɔt ðəɾ ɪn kɪlɪŋ hɪm, hi hæd dɪfiɾəd ðə ʃædoʊ fəɹ ɡʊd.

The man didn't look from the fire as he laughed. It was a rough, low-throated laugh that held little true mirth. Once, Rand had known this man only as Ba'alzamon - a name for the Dark One - and had foolishly thought that in killing him, he had defeated the Shadow for good.

"aɪ wɑtʃt jə daɪ," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ stæb jə θɹu ðə tʃɛst wɪð kælændɝ. ɪʃə - "

"I watched you die," Rand said. "I stabbed you through the chest with Callandor. Isha - "

"ðæɾ ɪz nɑt maɪ neɪm," ðə mæn ɪntɝʌptɪd, stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ðə fleɪmz. "aɪ æm noʊn əz mɔɹaɪɾɪn, naʊ."

"That is not my name," the man interrupted, still watching the flames. "I am known as Moridin, now."

"ðə neɪm ɪz ɪɹɛləvənt," ɹænd sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. "ju ɑɹ dɛd, ən ðɪs ɪz dʒʌst ə dʒɹim."

"The name is irrelevant," Rand said angrily. "You are dead, and this is just a dream."

"dʒʌst ə dʒɹim," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, tʃʌklɪŋ. "jɛs." ðə mæn wɑz klæɾ ɪn ə blæk koʊɾ ən tʃɹaʊzɝz, ðə dɑɹknəs ɹɪlivd oʊnli baɪ ɹɛɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ðə slivz.

"Just a dream," Moridin said, chuckling. "Yes." The man was clad in a black coat and trousers, the darkness relieved only by red embroidery on the sleeves.

mɔɹaɪɾɪn faɪnəli lʊkt ət hɪm. fleɪmz fɹəm ðə faɪɝ kæs bɹaɪt ɹɛɾ ən ɔɹənʒ laɪɾ əkɹɔs ɪz æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs ən ənblɪŋkɪŋ aɪz. "waɪ dʒju ɔlweɪz waɪn ðət weɪ? dʒʌst ə dʒɹim. dʒju nɑt noʊ ðət mɛni dʒɹimz ɑɹ mɔɹ tʃɹuθfəl ðən ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld?"

Moridin finally looked at him. Flames from the fire cast bright red and orange light across his angular face and unblinking eyes. "Why do you always whine that way? Just a dream. Do you not know that many dreams are more truthful than the waking world?"

"ju ɑɹ dɛd," ɹænd ɹɪpiɾɪd stʌbɝnli.

"You are dead," Rand repeated stubbornly.

"soʊ ɑɹ ju. aɪ wɑtʃt jə daɪ, jə noʊ. læʃɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ə tɛmpəst, kɹieɪɾɪŋ ən ɪntaɪɝ maʊntən tə mɑɹk jəɹ kɛɹn. soʊ ɛɹəɡənt."

"So are you. I watched you die, you know. Lashing out in a tempest, creating an entire mountain to mark your cairn. So arrogant."

luz θɝɪn hæd - əpɑn dɪskʌvɝɪŋ ðət hid kɪld ɔl ðəɾ i lʌvd - dʒɹɔn əpɑn ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən dɪstʃɹɔɪd hɪmsɛlf, kɹieɪɾɪŋ dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn ɪn ðə pɹɑsɛs. mɛnʃən ə ðɪs ɪvɛn ɔlweɪz bɹɔɾ ɑn haʊlz ʌv ɡɹif ən æŋɡɝ ɪn ɹændz maɪnd.

Lews Therin had - upon discovering that he'd killed all that he loved - drawn upon the One Power and destroyed himself, creating Dragonmount in the process. Mention of this event always brought on howls of grief and anger in Rand's mind.

bʌt ðɪs taɪm, ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns.

But this time, there was silence.

mɔɹaɪɾɪn tɝn bæk tə wɑtʃ ðə hitləs fleɪmz. tə ðə saɪd, ɪn ðə stoʊnz ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ɹænd sɔ muvmənt. flɪkɝɪŋ bɪts ə ʃædoʊ, dʒʌs bɛɹli vɪzəbəl θɹu ðə kɹæks ɪn ðə stoʊnz. ðə ɹɛd-hɑt hit ʃoʊn bɪhaɪnd, laɪk ɹɑk tɝn moʊltən, ən ðoʊz ʃædoʊz muvd, fɹæntɪk. dʒʌs feɪnli, ɹænd kəd hɪɹ skɹætʃɪŋ. ɹæts, hi ɹilaɪzd. ðəɹ wɝ ɹæts bɪhaɪn ðə stoʊnz, biɪŋ kənsum baɪ ðə tɛɹəbəl hit tʃɹæpt ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ðɛɹ klɔz skɹætʃt, pʊʃɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹæks, əz ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɪskeɪp ðɛɹ bɝnɪŋ.

Moridin turned back to watch the heatless flames. To the side, in the stones of the fireplace, Rand saw movement. Flickering bits of shadow, just barely visible through the cracks in the stones. The red-hot heat shone behind, like rock turned molten, and those shadows moved, frantic. Just faintly, Rand could hear scratching. Rats, he realized. There were rats behind the stones, being consumed by the terrible heat trapped on the other side. Their claws scratched, pushing through the cracks, as they tried to escape their burning.

səm ə ðoʊz taɪni hænz simd ɔlmoʊs hjumən.

Some of those tiny hands seemed almost human.

dʒʌst ə dʒɹim, ɹænd toʊl hɪmsɛlf fɔɹsfəli. dʒʌst ə dʒɹim. bʌɾ i nu ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv wʌt mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæd sɛd. ɹændz ɛnəmi stɪl lɪvd. laɪt! haʊ mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz hæd ɹɪtɝn əz wɛl? æŋɡɝ meɪɾ ɪm ɡɹɪp ði ɑɹmɹɛst ə ðə tʃɛɹ. pɝhæps i ʃʊɾə bɪn tɛɹəfaɪd, bʌɾ i hæd stɑpt ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðɪs kɹitʃɝ ən ɪz mæstɝ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ɹænd hæd noʊ ɹum lɛft fəɹ fɪɹ. ɪn fækt, ɪt ʃəd bi mɔɹaɪɾɪn u fɪɹd, fəɹ ðə læs taɪm ðeɪ hæd mɛt, ɹænd hæd kɪl hɪm.

Just a dream, Rand told himself forcefully. Just a dream. But he knew the truth of what Moridin had said. Rand's enemy still lived. Light! How many of the others had returned as well? Anger made him grip the armrest of the chair. Perhaps he should have been terrified, but he had stopped running from this creature and his master long ago. Rand had no room left for fear. In fact, it should be Moridin who feared, for the last time they had met, Rand had killed him.

"haʊ?" ɹænd dɪmændəd.

"How?" Rand demanded.

"lɔŋ əɡoʊ, aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðət ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kəd ɹɪstɔɹ jəɹ lɔs lʌv. dʒju nɑt θɪŋk ðəɾ i kən izəli ɹɪkʌvɝ wʌn u sɝvz hɪm?"

"Long ago, I promised you that the Great Lord could restore your lost love. Do you not think that he can easily recover one who serves him?"

ənʌðɝ neɪm fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv. jɛs, ɪt wɑz tʃɹu, ivən ɪf ɹænd wɪʃt i kəd dɪnaɪ ɪt. waɪ ʃəɾ i bi sɝpɹaɪz tə si hɪz ɛnəmiz ɹɪtɝn, wən ðə dɑɹk wʌn kəd ɹɪstɔɹ ðə dɛd tə laɪf?

Another name for the Dark One was Lord of the Grave. Yes, it was true, even if Rand wished he could deny it. Why should he be surprised to see his enemies return, when the Dark One could restore the dead to life?

"wi ɑɹ ɔl ɹibɔɹn," mɔɹaɪɾɪn kəntɪnjud, "spʌn bæk ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn taɪm ən taɪm əɡɛn. dɛθ ɪz noʊ bæɹiɝ tə maɪ mæstɝ seɪv fəɹ ðoʊz u hæv noʊn bɑlfaɪɝ. ðeɪ ɑɹ bɪɑn ɪz ɡɹæsp. ɪts ə wʌndɝ wi kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɛm."

"We are all reborn," Moridin continued, "spun back into the Pattern time and time again. Death is no barrier to my master save for those who have known balefire. They are beyond his grasp. It is a wonder we can remember them."

soʊ səm ə ði ʌðɝz ɹɪli wɝ dɛd. bɑlfaɪɝ wɑz ðə ki. bʌt haʊ hæd mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɡɑɾən ɪndə ɹændz dʒɹimz? ɹænd sɛt wɔɹdz itʃ naɪt. hi ɡlænst ət mɔɹaɪɾɪn, noʊɾɪsɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɑɾ əbaʊt ðə mænz aɪz. smɔl blæk spɛks floʊɾəd əbaʊɾ ɪn ðə waɪts, kɹɔsɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ laɪk bɪts ʌv æʃ bloʊn ɑn ə lizɝli wɪnd.

So some of the others really were dead. Balefire was the key. But how had Moridin gotten into Rand's dreams? Rand set wards each night. He glanced at Moridin, noticing something odd about the man's eyes. Small black specks floated about in the whites, crossing back and forth like bits of ash blown on a leisurely wind.

"ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kən ɡɹæn jə sænəɾi, jə noʊ," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd.

"The Great Lord can grant you sanity, you know," Moridin said.

"jɔɹ læst ɡɪft ə sænəɾi bɹɔt mi noʊ kʌmfɝt," ɹænd sɛd, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ hɪmsɛlf wɪð ðə wɝdz.

"Your last gift of sanity brought me no comfort," Rand said, surprising himself with the words.

ðət hæd bɪn luz θɝɪnz mɛmɹi, nɑɾ ɪz oʊn. jɛt luz θɝɪn wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm ɪz maɪnd. ɑdli, ɹænd fɛl mɔɹ steɪbəl - sʌmhaʊ - hɪɹ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs wɛɹ ɔl ɛls əpɪɹd fluəd. ðə pisəz ə hɪmsɛlf fɪt təɡɛðɝ bɛɾɝ. nɑt pɝfəkli, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt bɛɾɝ ðən ðeɪ hæɾ ɪn ɹisən mɛmɹi.

That had been Lews Therin's memory, not his own. Yet Lews Therin was gone from his mind. Oddly, Rand felt more stable - somehow - here in this place where all else appeared fluid. The pieces of himself fit together better. Not perfectly, of course, but better than they had in recent memory.

mɔɹaɪɾɪn snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ɹænd tɝn bæk tə ðə fleɪmz, wɑtʃɪŋ əm twɪst ən flɪkɝ. ðeɪ fɔɹmd ʃeɪps, laɪk ðə klaʊdz, bʌt ðiz wɝ hɛdləs bɑɾiz, skɛləɾəl, bæks ɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪn peɪn, ɹaɪðɪŋ fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪn faɪɝ, spæzəmɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ flæʃɪŋ ɪndə nʌθɪŋ.

Moridin snorted softly, but said nothing. Rand turned back to the flames, watching them twist and flicker. They formed shapes, like the clouds, but these were headless bodies, skeletal, backs arching in pain, writhing for a moment in fire, spasming, before flashing into nothing.

ɹænd wɑtʃt ðət faɪɝ fəɹ ə taɪm, θɪŋkɪŋ. wʌn maɪɾ əv θɔt ðət ðeɪ wɝ tu oʊl fɹɛnz, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə wɔɹmθ ʌv ə wɪntɝ hɑɹθ. ɪksɛp ðət ðə fleɪmz ɡeɪv noʊ hit, ən ɹænd wəd sʌmdeɪ kɪl ðɪs mæn əɡɛn. əɹ daɪ əɾ ɪz hænz.

Rand watched that fire for a time, thinking. One might have thought that they were two old friends, enjoying the warmth of a winter hearth. Except that the flames gave no heat, and Rand would someday kill this man again. Or die at his hands.

mɔɹaɪɾɪn tæpt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ. "waɪ hæv jə kʌm hɪɹ?"

Moridin tapped his fingers on the chair. "Why have you come here?"

kʌm hɪɹ? ɹænd θɔt, wɪð ʃɑk. hædn mɔɹaɪɾɪn bɹɔt hɪm?

Come here? Rand thought, with shock. Hadn't Moridin brought him?

"aɪ fil soʊ taɪɝd," mɔɹaɪɾɪn kəntɪnjud, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz. "ɪz ðət ju, əɹ ɪz ɪt mi? aɪ kəd θɹɑɾəl sɛmɝhɪdʒ fəɹ wʌt ʃi dɪd."

"I feel so tired," Moridin continued, closing his eyes. "Is that you, or is it me? I could throttle Semirhage for what she did."

ɹænd fɹaʊnd. wɑz mɔɹaɪɾɪn mæd? ɪʃəml hæd sɝɾənli sim kɹeɪzi, ət ði ɛnd.

Rand frowned. Was Moridin mad? Ishamael had certainly seemed crazy, at the end.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt taɪm fəɹ əs tə faɪt," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ə hæn ət ɹænd. "ɡoʊ. liv mi ɪn pis. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌt wəd hæpən tə əs ɪf wi kɪld wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wɪl əv jə sun ɪnʌf. hɪz vɪktɝi ɪz əʃʊɹd."

"It is not time for us to fight," Moridin said, waving a hand at Rand. "Go. Leave me in peace. I do not know what would happen to us if we killed one another. The Great Lord will have you soon enough. His victory is assured."

"hi hæz feɪl bɪfɔɹ ən wɪl feɪl əɡɛn," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ wɪl dɪfit hɪm."

"He has failed before and will fail again," Rand said. "I will defeat him."

mɔɹaɪɾɪn læft əɡɛn, ðə seɪm hɑɹtləs læf əz bɪfɔɹ. "pɝhæps jə wɪl," hi sɛd. "bʌt dʒju θɪŋk ðət mæɾɝz? kənsɪɾɝ ɪt. ðə wil tɝnz, taɪm ən taɪm əɡɛn. oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ ði eɪdʒəz tɝn, ən mɛn faɪt ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. bʌt sʌmdeɪ, hɪl wɪn, ən wən i dʌz, ðə wil wɪl stɑp.

Moridin laughed again, the same heartless laugh as before. "Perhaps you will," he said. "But do you think that matters? Consider it. The Wheel turns, time and time again. Over and over the Ages turn, and men fight the Great Lord. But someday, he will win, and when he does, the Wheel will stop.

"ðæɾ ɪz waɪ hɪz vɪktɝi ɪz əʃʊɹd. aɪ θɪŋk ɪɾəl bi ðɪs eɪdʒ, bʌɾ ɪf nɑt, ðən ɪn ənʌðɝ. wən jə ɑɹ vɪktɔɹiəs, ɪɾ oʊnli lidz tə ənʌðɝ bæɾəl. wən hiz vɪktɔɹiəs, ɔl θɪŋz wɪl ɛnd. kən jə nɑt si ðət ðəɹ ɪz noʊ hoʊp fəɹ ju?"

"That is why his victory is assured. I think it will be this Age, but if not, then in another. When you are victorious, it only leads to another battle. When he is victorious, all things will end. Can you not see that there is no hope for you?"

"ɪz ðət wʌt meɪd jə tɝn tə hɪz saɪd?" ɹænd æskt. "ju wɝ ɔlweɪz soʊ fʊl ə θɔts, ilən.

"Is that what made you turn to his side?" Rand asked. "You were always so full of thoughts, Elan.

jəɹ lɑdʒɪk dɪstʃɹɔɪd ju, dɪdn ɪt?"

Your logic destroyed you, didn't it?"

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ pæθ tə vɪktɝi," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd. "ði oʊnli pæθ ɪz tə fɑloʊ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ən ɹul fəɹ ə taɪm bɪfɔɹ ɔl θɪŋz ɛnd. ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ fulz. ðeɪ lʊk fəɹ ɡɹæn ɹɪwɔɹdz ɪn ði ɪɾɝnɪtiz, bʌt ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ ɪɾɝnɪtiz. oʊnli ðə naʊ, ðə læs deɪz."

"There is no path to victory," Moridin said. "The only path is to follow the Great Lord and rule for a time before all things end. The others are fools. They look for grand rewards in the eternities, but there will be no eternities. Only the now, the last days."

hi læft əɡɛn, ən ðɪs taɪm ðəɹ wɑz dʒɔɪ ɪn ɪt. tʃɹu plɛʒɝ.

He laughed again, and this time there was joy in it. True pleasure.

ɹænd stʊd. mɔɹaɪɾɪn aɪɾ ɪm wɛɹəli, bʌt dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ ʌp.

Rand stood. Moridin eyed him warily, but did not get up.

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə weɪ tə wɪn, mɔɹaɪɾɪn," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ min tə kɪl hɪm. sleɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. lɛt ðə wil tɝn wɪθaʊɾ ɪz kɑnstən teɪnt."

"There is a way to win, Moridin," Rand said. "I mean to kill him. Slay the Dark One. Let the Wheel turn without his constant taint."

mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɡeɪv noʊ ɹiækʃən. hi wɑz stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə fleɪmz. "wi ɑɹ kənɛktəd," mɔɹaɪɾɪn faɪnəli sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz haʊ jə keɪm hɪɹ, aɪ səspɛkt, ðoʊ aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn əɹ bɑn maɪsɛlf. aɪ daʊt jə kən ʌndɝstæn ðə mæɡnətuɾ ə ðə stupɪɾɪti ɪn jəɹ steɪtmənt."

Moridin gave no reaction. He was still staring at the flames. "We are connected," Moridin finally said. "That is how you came here, I suspect, though I do not understand our bond myself. I doubt you can understand the magnitude of the stupidity in your statement."

ɹænd fɛlt ə flæʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ, bʌt fɔɾ ɪt daʊn. hi wəd nɑt bi ɡoʊɾɪd. "wi ʃæl si."

Rand felt a flash of anger, but fought it down. He would not be goaded. "We shall see."

hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪt wɑz dɪstənt, fɑɹ əweɪ. ɹænd sizd ɪt, ən fɛl hɪmsɛlf jæŋkt əweɪ, əz ɪf ɑn ə laɪn ə seɪɾɪn. ðə ɹum vænɪʃt, ən soʊ dɪd ðə wʌn paʊɝ, əz ɹænd ɛntɝɾ ə dip blæknəs.

He reached for the One Power. It was distant, far away. Rand seized it, and felt himself yanked away, as if on a line of saidin. The room vanished, and so did the One Power, as Rand entered a deep blackness.

ɹænd faɪnəli stɑp θɹæʃɪŋ ɪn ɪz slip, ən mɪn hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ, hoʊpɪŋ ðəɾ i wʊdn stɑɹɾ əɡɛn. ʃi sæt, lɛɡz tʌkt ʌndɝniθ hɝ, ɹæpt ɪn ə blæŋkəɾ əz ʃi ɹɛɾ ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum. ə smɔl læmp flɪkɝɾ ən dænst ɑn ðə ʃɔɹt teɪbəl bɪsaɪd hɝ, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ əɹ stæk ə mʌsti bʊks. fɔlɪŋ ʃeɪl, mɑɹks ən ɹɪmɑɹks, mɑnjəməns pæst. hɪstɝiz, moʊst ə ðɛm.

Rand finally stopped thrashing in his sleep, and Min held her breath, hoping that he wouldn't start again. She sat, legs tucked underneath her, wrapped in a blanket as she read in her chair at the corner of the room. A small lamp flickered and danced on the short table beside her, illuminating her stack of musty books. Falling Shale, Marks and Remarks, Monuments Past. Histories, most of them.

ɹænd saɪd sɔfli, bʌt dɪd nɑt muv. mɪn ɹilist əɹ bɹɛθ ən sɛɾəld bæk ɪndə hɝ tʃɛɹ, fɪŋɡɝ mɑɹkɪŋ əɹ pleɪs ɪn ə kɑpi ʌv pɛlæɾioʊzəz pɑndɝɪŋz. wɪð ðə ʃʌɾɝz kloʊz fəɹ ðə naɪt, ʃi kəd stɪl hɪɹ ðə wɪn sɔ ɪn ðə paɪnz. ðə ɹum smɛl feɪnli ʌv smoʊk fɹəm ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ faɪɝ. eɪvinhəz kwɪk θɪŋkɪŋ hæd meɪɾ ə pətɛnʃəl dɪzæstɝ ɪndə ə mɪɹ ɪnkənvinjəns. nɑt ðət ʃi wɑz biɪŋ ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd fəɹ ɪt. ðə waɪz wʌnz kəntɪnjud tə wɝk əɹ əz hɑɹɾ əz ə mɝtʃəns læs mjul.

Rand sighed softly, but did not move. Min released her breath and settled back into her chair, finger marking her place in a copy of Pelateos's Ponderings. With the shutters closed for the night, she could still hear the wind sough in the pines. The room smelled faintly of smoke from the strange fire. Aviendha's quick thinking had made a potential disaster into a mere inconvenience. Not that she was being rewarded for it. The Wise Ones continued to work her as hard as a merchant's last mule.

mɪn hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɝ tə hæv ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðət ðeɪd bɪn ɪn ðə kæmp təɡɛðɝ fəɹ səm taɪm naʊ. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ haʊ tə θɪŋk ə ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. ðeɪ hæd bɪkʌm ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ ðəɾ ivnɪŋ, ʃɛɹɪŋ uskaɪ. bʌt wʌn deɪ dɪd nɑt fɹɛnz meɪk, ən ʃi wɑz dɛfənətli ənkʌmftəɹbəl əbaʊt ʃɛɹɪŋ.

Min hadn't been able to get close enough to her to have a conversation, despite the fact that they'd been in the camp together for some time now. She didn't know how to think of the other woman. They had become a little more comfortable with one another that evening, sharing oosquai. But one day did not friends make, and she was definitely uncomfortable about sharing.

mɪn ɡlænst əɡɛn ət ɹænd, laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz bæk, aɪz kloʊzd, bɹɛθ kʌmɪŋ ivənli naʊ. hɪz lɛft ɑɹm leɪ əkɹɔs ɪz blæŋkəts, ðə stʌmp ɪkspoʊzd. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ haʊ hi mænədʒ tə slip, wɪð ðoʊz wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd. əz sun əz ʃi θɔɾ ə ðɛm, ʃi kəd fil ðə peɪn - ɪt wɑz ɔl pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹoʊld-ʌp bɔl ə ɹændz ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ maɪnd. ʃi hæd lɝn tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə peɪn. ʃid hæd tə. fəɹ hɪm, ɪt wəd bi mʌtʃ, mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ. haʊ hi kəd stæn ɪt, ʃi dɪdnt noʊ.

Min glanced again at Rand, lying on his back, eyes closed, breath coming evenly now. His left arm lay across his blankets, the stump exposed. She didn't know how he managed to sleep, with those wounds in his side. As soon as she thought of them, she could feel the pain - it was all part of the rolled-up ball of Rand's emotions in the back of her mind. She had learned to ignore the pain. She'd had to. For him, it would be much, much stronger. How he could stand it, she didn't know.

ʃi wɑzn ɛɛs sədaɪ - θæŋk ðə laɪt - bʌt sʌmhaʊ ʃi hæd bɑndəd hɪm. ɪt wɑz əmeɪzɪŋ; ʃi kəd tɛl wɛɹ i wɑz, tɛl ɪf i wɑz dɪstʃɹɔt. ʃi kəd moʊsli kip ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz fɹəm oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ əɹ ɪksɛpt wən ðeɪ wɝ pæʃənət. bʌt wʌt wʊmən dɪdnt wɑnə bi oʊvɝwɛlm dʊɹɪŋ ðoʊz moʊməns? ɪt wɑz ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli . . . ɪɡzɪlɝeɪɾɪŋ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð ðə bɑnd, wɪtʃ lɛɾ əɹ fil boʊθ əɹ oʊn dɪzaɪɝ ən ðə ɹeɪdʒɪŋ tɛmpəst ə faɪɝ ðət wɑz ɹændz dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ hɝ.

She wasn't Aes Sedai - thank the Light - but somehow she had bonded him. It was amazing; she could tell where he was, tell if he was distraught. She could mostly keep his emotions from overwhelming her except when they were passionate. But what woman didn't want to be overwhelmed during those moments? It was a particularly . . . exhilarating experience with the bond, which let her feel both her own desire and the raging tempest of fire that was Rand's desire for her.

ðə θɔt meɪɾ əɹ blʌʃ, ən ʃi pʊld oʊpən pɑndɝɪŋz tə dɪstʃɹæk hɝsɛlf. ɹænd niɾəd ɪz slip, ən ʃi wɑz gɑnə lɛɾ ɪm əv ɪt. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi niɾəd tə stʌɾi, ɔlðoʊ ʃi wɑz kənfɹʌntəd baɪ kənkluʒənz ðət ʃi dɪdn laɪk.

The thought made her blush, and she pulled open Ponderings to distract herself. Rand needed his sleep, and she was going to let him have it. Besides, she needed to study, although she was confronted by conclusions that she didn't like.

ðiz bʊks hæd bɪlɔŋ tə hɹɪd fɛl, ðə kaɪnli oʊl skɑlɝ u hæd dʒɔɪn ɹændz skul ɪn kɛɹhin. mɪn smaɪld, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ fɛlz dɪstʃɹæktəd weɪ ʌv tɔkɪŋ ən ɪz kənfjuzd - jɛt sʌmhaʊ bɹɪljənt - dɪskʌvɝiz.

These books had belonged to Herid Fel, the kindly old scholar who had joined Rand's school in Cairhien. Min smiled, remembering Fel's distracted way of talking and his confused - yet somehow brilliant - discoveries.

hɹɪd fɛl wɑz dɛd naʊ, mɝɾɝd, tɔɹn əpɑɹt baɪ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. hid dɪskʌvɝd sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðiz bʊks, sʌmθɪŋ hiɾ ɪntɛndəd tə tɛl ɹænd. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə læs bæɾəl ən ðə silz ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. fɛl hæd bɪn kɪl dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ i kəd pæs ɑn ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz koʊɪnsɪɾəns; pɝhæps ðə bʊks hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪz dɛθ. bʌt pɝhæps ðeɪ dɪd. mɪn wɑz dɪtɝmən tə faɪn ði ænsɝz. fəɹ ɹænd, ən fəɹ hɹɪd hɪmsɛlf.

Herid Fel was dead now, murdered, torn apart by Shadowspawn. He'd discovered something in these books, something he'd intended to tell Rand. Something about the Last Battle and the seals on the Dark One's prison. Fel had been killed just before he could pass on the information. Perhaps it was coincidence; perhaps the books had nothing to do with his death. But perhaps they did. Min was determined to find the answers. For Rand, and for Herid himself.

ʃi pʊt daʊn pɑndɝɪŋz ən pɪkt ʌp θɔts əmʌŋ ðə ɹuənz, ə wɝk fɹəm oʊvɝ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ. ʃid mɑɹkt ə pleɪs wɪð ə smɔl slɪp ə peɪpɝ, ðə vɛɹi seɪm naʊ-wɔɹn noʊt ðət hɹɪd hæd sɛn tə ɹænd ʃɔɹtli bɪfɔɹ ðə mɝɾɝ. mɪn tɝn ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ɹɛɾɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛn.

She put down Ponderings and picked up Thoughts Among the Ruins, a work from over a thousand years ago. She'd marked a place with a small slip of paper, the very same now-worn note that Herid had sent to Rand shortly before the murder. Min turned it over in her fingers, reading it again.

bɪlif ən ɔɹɾɝ ɡɪv stʃɹɛŋkθ. hæv tə klɪɹ ɹʌbəl bɪfɔɹ jə kən bɪld. wɪl ɪkspleɪn wən si jə nɛkst. də nɑt bɹɪŋ ɡɝl. tu pɹɪɾi.

Belief and order give strength. Have to clear rubble before you can build. Will explain when see you next. Do not bring girl. Too pretty.

ʃi fɪɡjɝd - fɹəm ɹɛɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ɪz bʊks - ðət ʃi kəd tʃɹeɪs ɪz θɔts. ɹænd hæd wɑntəɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɑn haʊ tə sil ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. kəd fɛl əv dɪskʌvɝd wʌt ʃi θɔt ʃi hæd?

She figured - from reading among his books - that she could trace his thoughts. Rand had wanted information on how to seal the Dark One's prison. Could Fel have discovered what she thought she had?

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. wʌt wɑz ʃi duɪŋ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɑlv ə skɑlɝli mɪstɝi? bʌɾ u ɛls wɑz ðɛɹ? wʌn ə ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ maɪt bi bɛɾɝ suɾəd, bʌt kəd ðeɪ bi tʃɹʌstɪd? ivən ðoʊz u hæd meɪd ðɛɹ oʊðz tə hɪm maɪt dɪsaɪd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɪn ɹændz bɛst ɪntʃɹəsts tə kip sikɹəts fɹəm hɪm.

She shook her head. What was she doing trying to solve a scholarly mystery? But who else was there? One of the Brown Ajah might be better suited, but could they be trusted? Even those who had made their oaths to him might decide that it was in Rand's best interests to keep secrets from him.

ɹænd hɪmsɛlf wɑz fɑɹ tu bɪzi, ən i wɑz tu ɪmpeɪʃən fəɹ bʊks leɪtli ɛniweɪ. ðət lɛf mɪn. ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə pis təɡɛðɝ səm ʌv wʌɾ i wəɾ əv tə du, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ - soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ - ðət wɑz stɪl ənnoʊn. ʃi fɛlt ʃi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊz, bʌɾ ɪt wɝiɾ əɹ tə ɹɪvil wʌt ʃid dɪskʌvɝd tə ɹænd. haʊ wəɾ i ɹɪspɑnd?

Rand himself was far too busy, and he was too impatient for books lately anyway. That left Min. She was beginning to piece together some of what he would have to do, but there was more - so much more - that was still unknown. She felt she was getting close, but it worried her to reveal what she'd discovered to Rand. How would he respond?

ʃi saɪd, skænɪŋ ðə bʊk. ʃid nɛvɝ θɔt ðət ʃi, ʌv ɔl pipəl, wəd bɪkʌm ə ful fəɹ səm mæn. jɛt hɪɹ ʃi wɑz, fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm wɛɹɛvɝ i wɛnt, pʊɾɪŋ ɪz nidz bɪfɔɹ əɹ oʊn.

She sighed, scanning the book. She'd never thought that she, of all people, would become a fool for some man. Yet here she was, following him wherever he went, putting his needs before her own.

ðət dɪdn min ʃi wɑz ɪz pɛt, ɹəɡɑɹdləs wʌt səm ə ðə pipəl ɪn kæmp sɛd. ʃi fɑloʊd ɹænd kəz ʃi lʌv hɪm, ən ʃi kəd fil - lɪɾɝəli - ðəɾ i ɹɪtɝn əɹ lʌv. dɪspaɪt ðə hɑɹʃnəs ðət wɑz ɪnveɪɾɪŋ ɪm bɪt baɪ bɪt, dɪspaɪt ði æŋɡɝ ən ðə bliknəs ə hɪz laɪf, hi lʌv hɝ. ən soʊ ʃi dɪd wʌt ʃi kəd tə hɛlp hɪm.

That didn't mean she was his pet, regardless what some of the people in camp said. She followed Rand because she loved him, and she could feel - literally - that he returned her love. Despite the harshness that was invading him bit by bit, despite the anger and the bleakness of his life, he loved her. And so she did what she could to help him.

ɪf ʃi kəd hɛlp sɑlv ðɪs wʌn pʌzəl, ðə pʌzəl ə silɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, ʃi kəɾ ətʃiv sʌmθɪŋ nɑt dʒʌs fəɹ ɹænd, bʌt fəɹ ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf. wʌɾ ɪt mæɾɝ ɪf soʊlʒɝz ɪn ðə kæmp dɪdnt noʊ wʌɾ əɹ vælju wɑz? ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli bɛɾɝ ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn əsumd əɹ tə bi dɪsmɪsəbəl.

If she could help solve this one puzzle, the puzzle of sealing the Dark One's prison, she could achieve something not just for Rand, but for the world itself. What did it matter if soldiers in the camp didn't know what her value was? It was probably better if everyone assumed her to be dismissible.

ɛni əsæsən u keɪm tə kɪl ɹænd ʃəd θɪŋk ðəɾ i kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ mɪn. ðə wʊd-bi kɪlɝ wəd sun dɪskʌvɝ ðə naɪvz hɪɾən ɪn mɪnz slivz. ʃi wɑzn əz ɡʊd wɪð əm əz tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn wɑz, bʌt ʃi nu mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf tə kɪl.

Any assassin who came to kill Rand should think that he could ignore Min. The would-be killer would soon discover the knives hidden in Min's sleeves. She wasn't as good with them as Thom Merrilin was, but she knew more than enough to kill.

ɹænd tɝn ɪn ɪz slip, bʌt sɛɾəld daʊn əɡɛn. ʃi lʌv hɪm. ʃi hædn tʃoʊzən tə də soʊ, bʌɾ əɹ hɑɹt - əɹ ðə pæɾɝn, əɹ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðiz θɪŋz - hæd meɪd ðə dɪsɪʒən fəɹ hɝ. ən naʊ ʃi wʊdn tʃeɪnʒ əɹ filɪŋz ɪf ʃi kʊd. ɪf ɪt mɛn deɪnʒɝ, ɪf ɪt mɛn sʌfɝɪŋ ðə lʊks ə mɛn ɪn ðə kæmp, ɪf ɪt mɛnt . . . ʃɛɹɪŋ ɪm wɪð ʌðɝz.

Rand turned in his sleep, but settled down again. She loved him. She hadn't chosen to do so, but her heart - or the Pattern, or the Creator, or whatever was in charge of these things - had made the decision for her. And now she wouldn't change her feelings if she could. If it meant danger, if it meant suffering the looks of men in the camp, if it meant . . . sharing him with others.

ɹænd stɝɾ əɡɛn. ðɪs taɪm, hi ɡɹoʊn ən oʊpən ɪz aɪz, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn tə hɪz hɛd, sʌmhaʊ mænɪdʒɪŋ tə lʊk mɔɹ wɪɹi naʊ ðən i hæd wən hid ɡɔn tə slip. hi wɔɹ oʊnli hɪz smɔlkloʊðz, ən ɪz tʃɛst wɑz bɛɹ. hi sæt laɪk ðət fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ðən stʊɾ ʌp, wɔkɪŋ tə ðə ʃʌɾɝd wɪndoʊ.

Rand stirred again. This time, he groaned and opened his eyes, sitting up. He raised his hand to his head, somehow managing to look more weary now than he had when he'd gone to sleep. He wore only his smallclothes, and his chest was bare. He sat like that for a long moment, then stood up, walking to the shuttered window.

mɪn pʊʃt əɹ bʊk kloʊzd. "ænd wʌt dʒju θɪŋk jəɹ duɪŋ, ʃifɝɾɝ? jə bɛɹli slɛp fəɹ ə kʌpəl ʌv aʊɝz!"

Min pushed her book closed. "And what do you think you're doing, sheepherder? You barely slept for a couple of hours!"

hi oʊpən ðə ʃʌɾɝz ən ðə wɪndoʊ, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ðə dɑɹk naɪt bɪɑnd. ə stʃɹeɪ kɝl ʌv wɪn meɪɾ əɹ læmp fleɪm ʃɪvɝ.

He opened the shutters and the window, exposing the dark night beyond. A stray curl of wind made her lamp flame shiver.

"ɹænd?" mɪn æskt.

"Rand?" Min asked.

ʃi kəd bɛɹli hɪɹ ɪz vɔɪs wən i ɹɪplaɪd. "hiz ɪnsaɪd maɪ hɛd. hi wɑz ɡɔn dʊɹɪŋ ðə dʒɹim. bʌt hiz bæk naʊ."

She could barely hear his voice when he replied. "He's inside my head. He was gone during the dream. But he's back now."

ʃi ɹɪzɪstɪd sɪŋkɪŋ daʊn ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. laɪt, bʌt ʃi heɪɾəd hɪɹɪŋ əbaʊt ɹændz mædnəs. ʃid hoʊp ðət wən i hil seɪɾɪn, hi wəd bi fɹi ʌv ðə teɪns ɪnsænəɾiz. "hi?" ʃi æskt, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs tə bi stɛɾi. "ðə vɔɪs ʌv . . . luz θɝɪn?"

She resisted sinking down in her chair. Light, but she hated hearing about Rand's madness. She'd hoped that when he healed saidin, he would be free of the taint's insanities. "He?" she asked, forcing her voice to be steady. "The voice of . . . Lews Therin?"

hi tɝnd, klaʊɾəd naɪt skaɪ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊ fɹeɪmɪŋ ɪz feɪs, ðə læmps ənivən ɪluməneɪʃən livɪŋ ɪz fitʃɝz moʊsli ɪn ʃædoʊz.

He turned, clouded night sky outside the window framing his face, the lamp's uneven illumination leaving his features mostly in shadows.

"ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ əɹ bʊk əsaɪɾ ən dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɪm bɪsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊ. "ju hæv tə tɔk tə sʌmwʌn. jə kæn kip ɪɾ ɔl ɪnsaɪd."

"Rand," she said, setting her book aside and joining him beside the window. "You have to talk to someone. You can't keep it all inside."

"aɪ hæv tə bi stʃɹɔŋ."

"I have to be strong."

ʃi tʌɡd ɑn ɪz ɑɹm, tɝnɪŋ ɪm təwɔɹd hɝ. "kipɪŋ mi əweɪ minz jəɹ stʃɹɔŋ?"

She tugged on his arm, turning him toward her. "Keeping me away means you're strong?"

"aɪm nɑt - "

"I'm not - "

"jɛs jə ɑɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðɛɹ, bɪhaɪn ðoʊz il aɪz ə jʊɹz. ɹænd, dʒju θɪŋk əl stɑp lʌvɪŋ jə kəz ʌv wʌt jə hɪɹ?"

"Yes you are. There are things going on in there, behind those Aiel eyes of yours. Rand, do you think I will stop loving you because of what you hear?"

"jul bi fɹaɪɾənd."

"You'll be frightened."

"oʊ," ʃi sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "soʊ ɪm ə fɹædʒəl flaʊɝ, æm aɪ?"

"Oh," she said, folding her arms. "So I'm a fragile flower, am I?"

hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ fəɹ wɝdz, ɪn ðə weɪ hi wʌns hæd. bæk wən hid bɪn nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə ʃifɝɾɝ ɑn ən ædvɛntʃɝ. "mɪn, aɪ noʊ jəɹ stʃɹɔŋ. jə noʊ aɪ du."

He opened his mouth, struggling for words, in the way he once had. Back when he'd been nothing more than a sheepherder on an adventure. "Min, I know you're strong. You know I do."
