"ðɛn tʃɹʌs mi tə bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bɛɹ wʌɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪd ju," ʃi sɛd. "wi kæn dʒʌs pɹitɛnd nʌθɪŋ əz hæpənd." ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf ɔnwɝd. "ðə teɪn lɛf mɑɹks ɑn ju. aɪ noʊ ɪt dɪd. bʌɾ ɪf jə kænt ʃɛɹ ɪt wɪð mi, hu kən jə ʃɛɹ ɪt wɪð?"

"Then trust me to be strong enough to bear what is inside you," she said. "We can't just pretend nothing has happened." She forced herself onward. "The taint left marks on you. I know it did. But if you can't share it with me, who can you share it with?"

hi ɹæn ɪz hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ, ðən tɝn əweɪ, bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə peɪs. "bɝn ɪɾ ɔl, mɪn! ɪf maɪ ɛnəmiz dɪskʌvɝ maɪ wiknəsəz, ðəl ɪksplɔɪt ðɛm. aɪ fil blaɪnd. aɪm ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɑn ən ʌnfəmɪljɝ pæθ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ bɹeɪks ɪn ðə ɹoʊd, əɹ ɪf ðə hoʊl kɝs θɪŋ ɛnz ɪn ə klɪf!"

He ran his hand through his hair, then turned away, beginning to pace. "Burn it all, Min! If my enemies discover my weaknesses, they will exploit them. I feel blind. I'm running in the dark on an unfamiliar path. I don't know if there are breaks in the road, or if the whole cursed thing ends in a cliff!"

ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm əz i pæst, stɑpɪŋ hɪm. "tɛl mi."

She laid a hand on his arm as he passed, stopping him. "Tell me."

"jul θɪŋk aɪm mæd."

"You'll think I'm mad."

ʃi snɔɹɾɪd. "aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi θɪŋk jəɹ ə wʊl-hɛɾəd ful. kən ɪt bi mʌtʃ wɝs ðən ðæt?"

She snorted. "I already think you're a wool-headed fool. Can it be much worse than that?"

hi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd hɝ, ən səm ə ðə tɛnʃən lɛft ɪz feɪs. hi sæt daʊn ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə bɛd, saɪɪŋ sɔfli. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz pɹɑɡɹɛs.

He regarded her, and some of the tension left his face. He sat down on the edge of the bed, sighing softly. But it was progress.

"sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz ɹaɪt," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ hɪɹ . . . θɪŋz. ə vɔɪs. ðə vɔɪs ə luz θɝɪn, ðə dʒɹæɡən. hi spiks tə mi ən ɹɪspɑnz tə ðə wɝld ɝaʊn mi. səmtaɪmz, hi tʃɹaɪz tə siz seɪɾɪn fɹəm mi. ən . . . ən səmtaɪmz i səksidz. hiz waɪld, mɪn. ɪnseɪn. bʌt ðə θɪŋz i kən də wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɑɹ əmeɪzɪŋ."

"Semirhage was right," Rand said. "I hear . . . things. A voice. The voice of Lews Therin, the Dragon. He speaks to me and responds to the world around me. Sometimes, he tries to seize saidin from me. And . . . and sometimes he succeeds. He's wild, Min. Insane. But the things he can do with the One Power are amazing."

hi stɛɹɾ ɔf ɪndə ðə dɪstəns. mɪn ʃɪvɝd. laɪt! hi lɛt ðə vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ? wʌd ðət min? ðəɾ i lɛt ðə mæd pɑɹɾ ə hɪz bɹeɪn teɪk kəntʃɹoʊl?

He stared off into the distance. Min shivered. Light! He let the voice in his head wield the One Power? What did that mean? That he let the mad part of his brain take control?

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "sɛmɝhɪdʒ kleɪmz ðət ðɪs ɪz dʒʌst ɪnsænəɾi, tʃɹɪks ə maɪ maɪnd, bʌt luz θɝɪn noʊz θɪŋz - θɪŋz ðəɾ aɪ doʊnt. θɪŋz əbaʊt hɪstɝi, əbaʊt ðə wʌn paʊɝ. jə hæɾ ə vjuɪŋ ə mi ðət ʃoʊd tu pipəl mɝdʒɪŋ ɪndə wʌn. ðət minz ðət luz θɝɪn ən aɪ ɑɹ dɪstɪŋkt! tu pipəl, mɪn. hiz ɹil."

He shook his head. "Semirhage claims that this is just insanity, tricks of my mind, but Lews Therin knows things - things that I don't. Things about history, about the One Power. You had a viewing of me that showed two people merging into one. That means that Lews Therin and I are distinct! Two people, Min. He's real."

ʃi wɔkt oʊvɝ ən sæt nɛks tə hɪm. "ɹænd, hiz ju. əɹ jəɹ hɪm. spʌn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn əɡɛn. ðoʊz mɛmɹiz ən θɪŋz jə kən du, ðəɹ ɹɛmnəns fɹəm u jə wɝ bɪfɔɹ."

She walked over and sat next to him. "Rand, he's you. Or you're him. Spun out into the Pattern again. Those memories and things you can do, they're remnants from who you were before."

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛd. "mɪn, hiz ɪnseɪn ən aɪm nɑt. bɪsaɪdz, hi feɪld. aɪ woʊnt. aɪ woʊn də ɪt, mɪn. aɪ woʊn hɝt ðoʊz aɪ lʌv, əz i dɪd. ən wən aɪ dɪfit ðə dɑɹk wʌn, aɪ woʊn liv ɪm eɪbəl tə ɹɪtɝn ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ ən tɛɹɝaɪz əs əɡɛn."

"No," Rand said. "Min, he's insane and I'm not. Besides, he failed. I won't. I won't do it, Min. I won't hurt those I love, as he did. And when I defeat the Dark One, I won't leave him able to return a short time later and terrorize us again."

θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ə "ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ"? ʃi pʊɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm. "dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ?" ʃi æskt. "ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ənʌðɝ pɝsən, əɹ ɪf ðoʊz ɑɹ dʒʌs mɛmɹiz fɹəm bɪfɔɹ, ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɪz jusfəl."

Three thousand years a "short time later"? She put her arms around him. "Does it matter?" she asked. "If there is another person, or if those are just memories from before, the information is useful."

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd, simɪŋ dɪstən əɡɛn. "bʌɾ aɪm əfɹeɪd tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ. wən aɪ du, aɪ ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ ɪm teɪk kəntʃɹoʊl. hi kæn bi tʃɹʌstɪd. hi dɪdn min tə kɪl hɝ, bʌt ðət dʌzn tʃeɪnʒ ðə fæk ðəɾ i dɪd. laɪt . . . aɪlaɪɛnə. . . ."

"Yes," Rand said, seeming distant again. "But I'm afraid to use the One Power. When I do, I risk letting him take control. He can't be trusted. He didn't mean to kill her, but that doesn't change the fact that he did. Light . . . Ilyena. . . ."

wɑz ðɪs haʊ ɪt hæpən tə ɔl ə ðɛm? itʃ wʌn əsumɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪli seɪn, ən ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ði ʌðɝ pɝsən ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðɛm u dɪd hɔɹəbəl θɪŋz?

Was this how it happened to all of them? Each one assuming that they were really sane, and that it was the other person inside of them who did horrible things?

"ɪts dʌn naʊ, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ɪm kloʊs. "wʌtɛvɝ ðɪs vɔɪs ɪz, ɪt woʊnt ɡɹoʊ ɛni wɝs. seɪɾɪn ɪz klɛnzd."

"It's done now, Rand," she said, holding him close. "Whatever this voice is, it won't grow any worse. Saidin is cleansed."

ɹænd dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd, bʌɾ i dɪd ɹɪlæks. ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə filɪŋ ə hɪz wɔɹmθ bɪsaɪd hɝ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sɪns hid lɛf ðə wɪndoʊ oʊpən.

Rand didn't respond, but he did relax. She closed her eyes, enjoying the feeling of his warmth beside her, particularly since he'd left the window open.

"ɪʃəml lɪvz," ɹænd sɛd.

"Ishamael lives," Rand said.

ʃi snæpt əɹ aɪz oʊpən. "wʌt?" dʒʌst wən ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fil kʌmftəɹbəl!

She snapped her eyes open. "What?" Just when she was beginning to feel comfortable!

"aɪ vɪzəɾəd ɪm ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz," ɹænd sɛd. "æn bɪfɔɹ jə æsk, noʊ. ɪt wɑzn dʒʌst ə naɪtmɛɹ ən ɪt wɑzn mædnəs. ɪt wɑz ɹil, ən aɪ kæn ɪkspleɪn haʊ aɪ noʊ. jəl dʒʌst əv tə tʃɹʌs mi."

"I visited him in the World of Dreams," Rand said. "And before you ask, no. It wasn't just a nightmare and it wasn't madness. It was real, and I can't explain how I know. You will just have to trust me."

"ɪʃəml," ʃi wɪspɝd. "ju kɪl hɪm!"

"Ishamael," she whispered. "You killed him!"

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. hiz ɹɪtɝnd, bɛɹɪŋ ə nu feɪs ən ə nu neɪm, bʌɾ ɪts hɪm. wi ʃʊɾə ɹilaɪzd ɪt wəd hæpən; ðə dɑɹk wʌn woʊn əbændən sətʃ jusfəl tulz wɪθaʊɾ ə faɪt. hi kən ɹitʃ bɪɑn ðə ɡɹeɪv."

"Yes," Rand said. "In the Stone of Tear. He has returned, bearing a new face and a new name, but it is him. We should have realized it would happen; the Dark One won't abandon such useful tools without a fight. He can reach beyond the grave."

"ðɛn haʊ kən wi wɪn? ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn wi kɪl dʒʌs kʌmz bæk əɡɛn. . . ."

"Then how can we win? If everyone we kill just comes back again. . . ."

"bɑlfaɪɝ," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪt wɪl kɪl əm fəɹ ɡʊd."

"Balefire," Rand said. "It will kill them for good."

"kædzueɪn sɛd - "

"Cadsuane said - "

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ wʌt kædzueɪn sɛd," hi snɑɹəld. "ʃi ɪz maɪ ædvaɪzɝ, ən ʃi ɡɪvz ædvaɪs. oʊnli ædvaɪs. aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən əl dɪsaɪd haʊ wi faɪt." hi stɑpt, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ.

"I don't care what Cadsuane said," he snarled. "She is my advisor, and she gives advice. Only advice. I am the Dragon Reborn, and I will decide how we fight." He stopped, taking a deep breath.

"ɛniweɪ, ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ ɪf ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɹɪtɝn, ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ u əɹ wʌt ðə dɑɹk wʌn sɛnz əɾ ʌs. ɪn ði ɛnd, əl dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm, ɪf pɑsəbəl. ɪf nɑt, ðən əl ət list sil ɪm əweɪ soʊ taɪtli ðət ðə wɝl kən fɝɡɛt hɪm."

"Anyway, it doesn't matter if the Forsaken return, it doesn't matter who or what the Dark One sends at us. In the end, I will destroy him, if possible. If not, then I will at least seal him away so tightly that the world can forget him."

hi ɡlæns daʊn ət hɝ. "fɔɹ ðət . . . aɪ nid ðə vɔɪs, mɪn. luz θɝɪn noʊz θɪŋz. əɹ . . . əɹ aɪ noʊ θɪŋz. wɪtʃɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz, ðə nɑlədʒ ɪz ðɛɹ. ɪn ə weɪ, ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn teɪnt wɪl dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm, fəɹ ɪts wʌt ɡeɪv mi æksɛs tə luz θɝɪn."

He glanced down at her. "For that . . . I need the voice, Min. Lews Therin knows things. Or . . . or I know things. Whichever it is, the knowledge is there. In a way, the Dark One's own taint will destroy him, for it is what gave me access to Lews Therin."

mɪn ɡlænst əɾ əɹ bʊks. hɹɪdz lɪɾəl slɪp ə peɪpɝ stɪl pik fɹəm ðə dɛpθs ə θɔts əmʌŋ ðə ɹuənz. "ɹænd," ʃi sɛd. "ju hæv tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə silz tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən."

Min glanced at her books. Herid's little slip of paper still peeked from the depths of Thoughts Among the Ruins. "Rand," she said. "You have to destroy the seals to the Dark One's prison."

hi lʊkt ət hɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

He looked at her, frowning.

"aɪm ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt," ʃi sɛd. "aɪv bɪn ɹiɾɪŋ hɹɪdz bʊks ɔl ðɪs taɪm, ən aɪ bɪliv ðæts wʌɾ i mɛn baɪ 'klɪɹɪŋ əweɪ ðə ɹʌbəl.' ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹibɪl ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, jəl fɝs nid tə oʊpən ɪt. klɪɹ əweɪ ðə pætʃ meɪɾ ɑn ðə bɔɹ."

"I'm sure of it," she said. "I've been reading Herid's books all this time, and I believe that's what he meant by 'clearing away the rubble.' In order to rebuild the Dark One's prison, you will first need to open it. Clear away the patch made on the Bore."

ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə bi ɪnkɹɛdʒələs. ʃɑkɪŋli, hi dʒʌs nɑɾəd. "jɛs," hi sɛd. "jɛs, ðət saʊnz ɹaɪt. aɪ daʊt ðət mɛni wɪl wɪʃ tə hɪɹ ɪt. ɪf ðoʊz silz ɑɹ bɹoʊkən, ðəɹ ɪz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl wʌt wɪl hæpən. ɪf aɪ feɪl tə kənteɪn ɪm . . ."

She had expected him to be incredulous. Shockingly, he just nodded. "Yes," he said. "Yes, that sounds right. I doubt that many will wish to hear it. If those seals are broken, there is no way to tell what will happen. If I fail to contain him . . ."

ðə pɹɑfəsiz dɪdn seɪ ɹænd wəd wɪn. oʊnli ðəɾ i wəd faɪt. mɪn ʃɪvɝɾ əɡɛn -  blæstəd wɪndoʊ! - bʌt mɛt ɹændz ɡeɪz. "jul wɪn. jəl dɪfit hɪm."

The prophecies didn't say Rand would win. Only that he would fight. Min shivered again -  blasted window! - but met Rand's gaze. "You'll win. You'll defeat him."

hi saɪd. "feɪθ ɪn ə mædmæn, mɪn?"

He sighed. "Faith in a madman, Min?"

"feɪθ ɪn ju, ʃifɝɾɝ." sʌɾənli vjuɪŋz spʌn ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd. ʃi ɪɡnɔɹɾ əm moʊst ə ðə taɪm, ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ nu, bʌt naʊ ʃi pɪkt əm aʊt. faɪɝəfliz kənsumd ɪn dɑɹknəs. θɹi wɪmən bɪfɔɹ ə paɪɹ. flæʃɪz ə laɪt, dɑɹknəs, ʃædoʊ, saɪnz ə dɛθ, kɹaʊnz, ɪnʒɝiz, peɪn ən hoʊp. ə tɛmpəst ɝaʊn ɹænd ælθɹ, stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛni fɪzɪkəl stɔɹm.

"Faith in you, sheepherder." Suddenly viewings spun around his head. She ignored them most of the time, unless they were new, but now she picked them out. Fireflies consumed in darkness. Three women before a pyre. Flashes of light, darkness, shadow, signs of death, crowns, injuries, pain and hope. A tempest around Rand al'Thor, stronger than any physical storm.

"wi stɪl doʊnt noʊ wʌt tə du," hi sɛd. "ðə silz ɑɹ bɹɪɾəl ɪnʌf ðəɾ aɪ kəd bɹeɪk əm ɪn maɪ hænz, bʌt wʌt ðɛn? haʊ də aɪ stɑp hɪm? dʌz ɪt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ ə ðəɾ ɪn jəɹ bʊks?"

"We still don't know what to do," he said. "The seals are brittle enough that I could break them in my hands, but what then? How do I stop him? Does it say anything of that in your books?"

"ɪts hɑɹd tə tɛl," ʃi ədmɪɾəd. "ðə kluz - ɪf ðæts wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ - ɑɹ veɪɡ. əl kip lʊkɪŋ. aɪ pɹɑməs. əl faɪn ænsɝz fəɹ ju."

"It's hard to tell," she admitted. "The clues - if that's what they are - are vague. I will keep looking. I promise. I'll find answers for you."

hi nɑɾəd, ən ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə fil ɪz tʃɹʌs θɹu ðə bɑnd. ðət wɑz ə fɹaɪɾənɪŋli ɹɛɹ ɪmoʊʃən fɹəm ɪm ɹisənli, bʌɾ i dɪd sim sɑftɝ ðən i hæd dʊɹɪŋ pɹiviəs deɪz. stɪl stoʊn, bʌt pɝhæps wɪð səm fju kɹæks, wɪlɪŋ tə lɛɾ əɹ ɪnsaɪd. ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

He nodded, and she was surprised to feel his trust through the bond. That was a frighteningly rare emotion from him recently, but he did seem softer than he had during previous days. Still stone, but perhaps with some few cracks, willing to let her inside. It was a beginning.

ʃi taɪɾənd əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɪm ən kloʊzd əɹ aɪz əɡɛn. ə pleɪs tə bɪɡɪn, bʌt wɪð soʊ lɪɾəl taɪm lɛft. ɪt wəɾ əv tə du.

She tightened her arms around him and closed her eyes again. A place to begin, but with so little time left. It would have to do.

kɛɹfəli ʃildɪŋ əɹ bɝnɪŋ kændəl, eɪvinhə lɪt ðə poʊl-maʊntəd læntɝn. ɪt flɪkɝɾ əlaɪt, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹin ɝaʊn hɝ. slʌmbɝɪŋ soʊlʒɝz snɔɹɾ ɪn ɹoʊz ə tɛns. ði ivnɪŋ wɑz koʊld, ði ɛɹ kɹɪsp, ən bɹæntʃəz ɹæɾəld ɪn ðə dɪstəns. ə loʊnli aʊl huɾɪd. ən eɪvinhə wɑz ɪɡzɔstəd.

Carefully shielding her burning candle, Aviendha lit the pole-mounted lantern. It flickered alight, illuminating the green around her. Slumbering soldiers snored in rows of tents. The evening was cold, the air crisp, and branches rattled in the distance. A lonely owl hooted. And Aviendha was exhausted.

ʃid kɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnz fɪfti taɪmz, laɪɾɪŋ ðə læntɝn, bloʊɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt, ðən dʒɑɡɪŋ bæk əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹin ən laɪɾɪŋ əɹ kændəl ət ðə mænɝ bɪfɔɹ wɔkɪŋ kɛɹfəli - ʃildɪŋ ðə fleɪm - tə laɪt ðə læntɝn əɡɛn.

She'd crossed the grounds fifty times, lighting the lantern, blowing it out, then jogging back across the green and lighting her candle at the manor before walking carefully - shielding the flame - to light the lantern again.

ənʌðɝ mʌnθ ə ðiz pʌnɪʃməns ən ʃid pɹɑbli ɡoʊ əz mæɾ əz ə wɛtləndɝ. ðə waɪz wʌnz wəd weɪk wʌn mɔɹnɪŋ ən faɪn əɹ ɡoʊɪŋ fəɹ ə swɪm, əɹ kæɹiɪŋ ə hæf-fʊl wɔɾɝskɪn, əɹ -  ivən - ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə hɔɹs fəɹ plɛʒɝ! ʃi saɪd, tu ɪɡzɔstəd tə θɪŋk ɛni fɝðɝ, ən tɝn təwɔɹd ði il sɛkʃən ə kæmp tə faɪnəli slip.

Another month of these punishments and she'd probably go as mad as a wetlander. The Wise Ones would wake one morning and find her going for a swim, or carrying a half-full waterskin, or -  even - riding a horse for pleasure! She sighed, too exhausted to think any further, and turned toward the Aiel section of camp to finally sleep.

sʌmwʌn wɑz stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Someone was standing behind her.

ʃi stɑɹɾəd, hænd ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɝ dæɡɝ, bʌt ɹɪlækst əz ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd æmɪz. ʌv ɔl ðə waɪz wʌnz, oʊnli ʃi - ə fɔɹmɝ meɪɾən - cʊɾə snikt ʌp ɑn eɪvinhə.

She started, hand going to her dagger, but relaxed as she recognized Amys. Of all the Wise Ones, only she - a former Maiden - could have sneaked up on Aviendha.

ðə waɪz wʌn stʊd wɪð hænz klæsp bɪfɔɹ hɝ, bɹaʊn ʃɔl ən skɝt flæpɪŋ slaɪtli ɪn ðə wɪnd. eɪvinhəz skɪn pɹɪkəld ət ðə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli tʃɪli ɡʌst. æmɪz' sɪlvɝ hɛɹ simd ɔlmoʊst ɡoʊsli ɪn ði ivnɪŋ laɪt; ə paɪn niɾəl pæsɪŋ ɑn ðə bɹiz hæd ɡɑɾən lɑdʒd ɪn ɪt. "ju əpɹoʊtʃ jəɹ pʌnɪʃməns wɪð sətʃ . . . dɛɾəkeɪʃən, tʃaɪld," æmɪz sɛd.

The Wise One stood with hands clasped before her, brown shawl and skirt flapping slightly in the wind. Aviendha's skin prickled at the particularly chilly gust. Amys' silver hair seemed almost ghostly in the evening light; a pine needle passing on the breeze had gotten lodged in it. "You approach your punishments with such . . . dedication, child," Amys said.

eɪvinhə lʊk daʊn. pɔɪntɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ æktɪvəɾiz wɑz tə ʃeɪm hɝ. wɑz ʃi ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ə taɪm? hæd ðə waɪz wʌnz faɪnəli dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡɪv ʌp ɑn hɝ? "pliz, waɪz wʌn. aɪ oʊnli də əz duɾi dɪmænz."

Aviendha looked down. Pointing out her activities was to shame her. Was she running out of time? Had the Wise Ones finally decided to give up on her? "Please, Wise One. I only do as duty demands."

"jɛs, jə du," æmɪz sɛd. ʃi ɹitʃt ʌp, ɹʌnɪŋ əɹ hæn θɹu hɝ hɛɹ, ən faʊn ðə paɪn niɾəl, ðən lɛɾ ɪt dʒɹɑp tə ðə dɛd ɡɹæs. "ænd, ɔlsoʊ, jə də nɑt. səmtaɪmz, eɪvinhə, wəɹ soʊ kənsɝnd wɪð ðə θɪŋz wɪv dʌn ðət wi də nɑt stɑp tə kənsɪɾɝ ðə θɪŋz wɪv nɑt."

"Yes, you do," Amys said. She reached up, running her hand through her hair, and found the pine needle, then let it drop to the dead grass. "And, also, you do not. Sometimes, Aviendha, we are so concerned with the things we have done that we do not stop to consider the things we have not."

eɪvinhə wɑz ɡlæd fəɹ ðə dɑɹknəs, wɪtʃ hɪɾ əɹ ʃeɪmfəl blʌʃ. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ə soʊlʒɝ ɹæŋ ði ivnɪŋ bɛl tə tʃaɪm ði aʊɝ, ðə sɑf mɛɾəl ɹɪŋɪŋ wɪð ɪlɛvən mɛlənkɑli pilz. haʊ dɪd ʃi ɹɪspɑn tə æmɪz' kɑmɛns? ðəɹ dɪdn sim tə bi ɛni pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɑns.

Aviendha was glad for the darkness, which hid her shameful blush. In the distance, a soldier rang the evening bell to chime the hour, the soft metal ringing with eleven melancholy peals. How did she respond to Amys' comments? There didn't seem to be any proper response.

eɪvinhə wɑz seɪv baɪ ə flæʃ ə laɪt dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə kæmp. ɪt wɑz feɪnt, bʌɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ðə flɪkɝ wɑz izi tə noʊɾəs.

Aviendha was saved by a flash of light just beyond the camp. It was faint, but in the darkness, the flicker was easy to notice.

"wʌt?" ðə waɪz wʌn æskt, noʊɾɪsɪŋ eɪvinhəz ɡeɪz ən tɝnɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ɪt.

"What?" the Wise One asked, noticing Aviendha's gaze and turning to follow it.

"laɪt," eɪvinhə sɛd. "fɹʌm ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnz."

"Light," Aviendha said. "From the Traveling grounds."

æmɪz fɹaʊnd, ðən ðə tu ʌv əm muv təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹaʊnz. sun ðeɪ ɪnkaʊntɝd deɪmɝ flɪn, dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ, ə smɔl ɡɑɹɾ ə sɑldəiənz ən il wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ðə kæmp. wʌd wʌn θɪŋk ʌv ə kɹitʃɝ sətʃ əz flɪn? ðə teɪn hæd bɪn klɛnzd, bʌt ðɪs mæn - ən mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz -  hæd kʌm, æskɪŋ tə lɝn, bɪfɔɹ ðət hæd hæpənd. eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf wəɾ əv sunɝ ɛmbɹeɪst saɪtblɪndɝ hɪmsɛlf əz dʌn ðæt, bʌt ðeɪ hæd pɹuvən tə bi paʊɝfəl wɛpənz.

Amys frowned, then the two of them moved toward the grounds. Soon they encountered Damer Flinn, Davram Bashere, a small guard of Saldaeans and Aiel walking into the camp. What did one think of a creature such as Flinn? The taint had been cleansed, but this man - and many of the others -  had come, asking to learn, before that had happened. Aviendha herself would have sooner embraced Sightblinder himself as done that, but they had proven to be powerful weapons.

æmɪz ən eɪvinhə muv tə ðə saɪɾ əz ðə smɔl pɑɹɾi hɝid təwɔɹd ðə mænɝ haʊs, lɪɾ oʊnli baɪ ðə dɪstən flɪkɝɪŋ tɔɹtʃɪz ən ðə klaʊd-kʌvɝd skaɪ əbʌv. ðoʊ moʊst ə ðə fɔɹs sɛn tə mit ðə sintʃæn hæd bɪn meɪɾ ʌp ə bæʃɪɹz soʊlʒɝz, ðəɹ wɝ sɛvɹəl meɪɾənz ɪn ðə ɡɹup.

Amys and Aviendha moved to the side as the small party hurried toward the manor house, lit only by the distant flickering torches and the cloud-covered sky above. Though most of the force sent to meet the Seanchan had been made up of Bashere's soldiers, there were several Maidens in the group.

æmɪz lɑkt aɪz wɪð wʌn ə ðɛm, ən oʊldɝ wʊmən neɪm kɔɹænə. ʃi hʌŋ bæk, ən ðoʊ ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ʃi lʊkt kənsɝnd. pɝhæps æŋɡɹi.

Amys locked eyes with one of them, an older woman named Corana. She hung back, and though it was difficult to tell in the darkness, she looked concerned. Perhaps angry.

"wʌt nuz?" æmɪz æskt.

"What news?" Amys asked.

"ði ɪnveɪɾɝz, ðiz sintʃæn," kɔɹænə nɪɹli spæt ðə wɝd, "ðeɪ hæv əɡɹid tə ənʌðɝ miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn."

"The invaders, these Seanchan," Corana nearly spat the word, "they have agreed to another meeting with the Car'a'carn."

æmɪz nɑɾəd. kɔɹænə, haʊɛvɝ, snɪft ɑɾəbli, ʃɔɹt hɛɹ ɹʌfəlɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃɪl bɹiz.

Amys nodded. Corana, however, sniffed audibly, short hair ruffling in the chill breeze.

"spik," æmɪz sɛd.

"Speak," Amys said.

"ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn suz tu hɑɹd fəɹ pis," kɔɹænə ɹɪplaɪd. "ðiz sintʃæn əv ɡɪvən ɪm ɹizən tə dɪklɛɹ ə blʌd fjud, bʌɾ i sɪmpɝz ən pændɝz tə ðɛm. aɪ fil laɪk ə tʃɹeɪn dɔɡ, sɛn tə lɪk ðə fiɾ ʌv ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ."

"The Car'a'carn sues too hard for peace," Corana replied. "These Seanchan have given him reason to declare a blood feud, but he simpers and panders to them. I feel like a trained dog, sent to lick the feet of a stranger."

æmɪz ɡlænst əɾ eɪvinhə. "wʌt dʒju seɪ tə ðɪs, eɪvinhə?"

Amys glanced at Aviendha. "What do you say to this, Aviendha?"

"maɪ hɑɹɾ əɡɹiz wɪð əɹ wɝdz, waɪz wʌn. bʌt, waɪl ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɪz ə ful ɪn səm θɪŋz, hiz nɑt biɪŋ wʌn naʊ. maɪ maɪn əɡɹiz wɪð hɪm, ən ɪn ðɪs keɪs, ɪts ðə maɪn aɪ wəd fɑloʊ."

"My heart agrees with her words, Wise One. But, while the Car'a'carn is a fool in some things, he is not being one now. My mind agrees with him, and in this case, it is the mind I would follow."

"haʊ kən jə seɪ ðæt?" kɔɹænə snæpt. ʃi ɛmfəsaɪz ðə ju, əz ɪf tə ɪmplaɪ ðəɾ eɪvinhə -  ɹisənli ə meɪɾən - ʃəɾ ʌndɝstænd.

"How can you say that?" Corana snapped. She emphasized the you, as if to imply that Aviendha -  recently a Maiden - should understand.

"wɪtʃ ɪz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, kɔɹænə?" eɪvinhə ɹɪplaɪd ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn. "ði ɑɹɡjəmən juv wɪð ənʌðɝ meɪɾən, əɹ ðə fjud jəɹ klæn əz wɪð ɪts ɛnəmi?"

"Which is more important, Corana?" Aviendha replied raising her chin. "The argument you have with another Maiden, or the feud your clan has with its enemy?"

"ðə klæn kʌmz fɝst, ʌv kɔɹs. bʌt wʌt dʌz ðət mæɾɝ?"

"The clan comes first, of course. But what does that matter?"

"ðə sintʃæn dɪzɝv tə bi fɔt," eɪvinhə sɛd, "æn jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt ðəɾ ɪt peɪnz tə æsk əm fəɹ pis. bʌt jə fɝɡɛt ðət wɪv ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɛnəmi. saɪtblɪndɝ hɪmsɛlf əz ə fjud wɪð ɔl mɛn, ən əɹ duɾi ɪz lɑɹdʒɝ ðən fjudz bɪtwin neɪʃənz."

"The Seanchan deserve to be fought," Aviendha said, "and you are right that it pains to ask them for peace. But you forget that we have a greater enemy. Sightblinder himself has a feud with all men, and our duty is larger than feuds between nations."

æmɪz nɑɾəd. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi taɪm ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ðə sintʃæn ðə weɪɾ ʌv əɹ spɪɹz əɾ ənʌðɝ deɪt."

Amys nodded. "There will be time enough to show the Seanchan the weight of our spears at another date."

kɔɹænə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "waɪz wʌn, jə saʊn laɪk ə wɛtləndɝ. wʌt kɛɹ əv wi fəɹ ðɛɹ pɹɑfəsiz ən stɔɹiz? ɹænd ælθɹz duɾi əz kɑɹəkɑɹn ɪz mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɪz duɾi tə ðə wɛtləndɝz. hi mʌs lɛɾ əs tə ɡlɔɹi."

Corana shook her head. "Wise One, you sound like a wetlander. What care have we for their prophecies and stories? Rand al'Thor's duty as Car'a'carn is much greater than his duty to the wetlanders. He must lead us to glory."

æmɪz stɛɹd hɑɹʃli ət ðə blɑn meɪɾən. "ju spik laɪk ə ʃeɪɾoʊ."

Amys stared harshly at the blond Maiden. "You speak like a Shaido."

kɔɹænə lɑkt əɹ stɛɹ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən wɪltɪd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. "pɑɹɾən, waɪz wʌn," ʃi faɪnəli sɛd. "aɪ hæv toʊ. bʌt jə ʃəd noʊ ðət ðə sintʃæn hæɾ il ɪn ðɛɹ kæmp."

Corana locked her stare for a moment, then wilted, turning away. "Pardon, Wise One," she finally said. "I have toh. But you should know that the Seanchan had Aiel in their camp."

"wʌt?" eɪvinhə æskt.

"What?" Aviendha asked.

"ðeɪ wɝ liʃt," kɔɹænə sɛd, "laɪk ðɛɹ teɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ ʃoʊn ɔf laɪk pɹaɪzəz fəɹ əɹ ɝaɪvəl, aɪ səspɛkt. aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ əmʌŋ ðɛm."

"They were leashed," Corana said, "like their tame Aes Sedai. They were being shown off like prizes for our arrival, I suspect. I recognized many Shaido among them."

æmɪz hɪst sɔfli. ʃeɪɾoʊ əɹ nɑt, il biɪŋ hɛld əz deɪmeɪn wɑz ə ɡɹeɪv ɪnsəlt. ən ðə sintʃæn wɝ flɔntɪŋ ðɛɹ kæptɪvz. ʃi ɡɹɪpt əɹ dæɡɝ.

Amys hissed softly. Shaido or not, Aiel being held as damane was a grave insult. And the Seanchan were flaunting their captives. She gripped her dagger.

"wʌt dʒju seɪ naʊ?" æmɪz ɡlænst əɾ eɪvinhə.

"What do you say now?" Amys glanced at Aviendha.

eɪvinhə ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. "ðə seɪm, waɪz wʌn, ðoʊ aɪɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹæðɝ kʌɾ aʊt maɪ tʌŋ ðən ədmɪɾ ɪt."

Aviendha gritted her teeth. "The same, Wise One, though I'd almost rather cut out my tongue than admit it."

æmɪz nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ bæk ət kɔɹænə. "du nɑt θɪŋk ðət wɪl ɪɡnɔɹ ðɪs ɪnsəlt, kɔɹænə.

Amys nodded, looking back at Corana. "Do not think that we will ignore this insult, Corana.

vɛnʒəns wɪl kʌm. wʌns ðɪs wɔɹ ɪz dʌn, ðə sintʃæn wɪl fil ðə stɔɹm ʌv əɹ æɹoʊz ən ðə tɪps ʌv əɹ spɪɹz. bʌt nɑɾ əntɪl æftɝ. ɡoʊ tɛl ðə tu klæn tʃifs wʌt juv toʊl mi."

Vengeance will come. Once this war is done, the Seanchan will feel the storm of our arrows and the tips of our spears. But not until after. Go tell the two clan chiefs what you have told me."

kɔɹænə nɑɾəd - ʃi wəd miɾ əɹ toʊ leɪɾɝ, ɪn pɹaɪvət, wɪð æmɪz - ən lɛft. deɪmɝ flɪn ən ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹitʃt ðə mænɝ haʊs; wəd ðeɪ weɪk ɹænd? hi wɑz slipɪŋ naʊ, ðoʊ eɪvinhə hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə mjuɾ əɹ bɑn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɝ naɪts pʌnɪʃmənt, lɛst ʃi ɛndʒjʊɹ sɛnseɪʃənz ðət ʃid ɹæðɝ əv əvɔɪɾəd. ət list, ʃid ɹæðɝ əv əvɔɪɾəd əm sɛkəndhænd.

Corana nodded - she would meet her toh later, in private, with Amys - and left. Damer Flinn and the others had already reached the manor house; would they wake Rand? He was sleeping now, though Aviendha had been forced to mute her bond in the middle of her night's punishment, lest she endure sensations that she'd rather have avoided. At least, she'd rather have avoided them secondhand.

"ðɛɹ wɪl bi deɪnʒɝəs wɝdz ə ðɪs əmʌŋ ðə spɪɹz," æmɪz sɛd θɔtfəli. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi kɔlz tə ətæk, dɪmænz ðət ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɡɪv ʌp ɪz ətɛmps tə meɪk pis."

"There will be dangerous words of this among the spears," Amys said thoughtfully. "There will be calls to attack, demands that the Car'a'carn give up his attempts to make peace."

"wɪl ðeɪ steɪ wɪð ɪm wən i ɹəfjuzəz?" eɪvinhə æskt.

"Will they stay with him when he refuses?" Aviendha asked.

"ʌv kɔɹs ðeɪ wɪl," æmɪz sɛd. "ðeɪɹ il." ʃi ɡlænst əɾ eɪvinhə. "wi hævən mʌtʃ taɪm, tʃaɪld. pɝhæps ɪts taɪm tə stɑp kɑɾəlɪŋ ju. əl θɪŋk ʌp bɛɾɝ pʌnɪʃməns fəɹ jə stɑɹɾɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ."

"Of course they will," Amys said. "They're Aiel." She glanced at Aviendha. "We haven't much time, child. Perhaps it is time to stop coddling you. I will think up better punishments for you starting tomorrow."

kɑɾəlɪŋ mi? eɪvinhə wɑtʃt æmɪz stɔk əweɪ. ðeɪ kʊdn pɑsəbli kʌm ʌp wɪð ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ jusləs əɹ dɪminɪŋ!

Coddling me? Aviendha watched Amys stalk away. They couldn't possibly come up with anything more useless or demeaning!

bʌt ʃid lɝn lɔŋ əɡoʊ nɑt tə ʌndɝɛstəmeɪɾ æmɪz. wɪð ə saɪ, eɪvinhə bɹoʊk ɪndə ə tʃɹɑt, hɛɾɪŋ bæk təwɔɹɾ əɹ tɛnt.

But she'd learned long ago not to underestimate Amys. With a sigh, Aviendha broke into a trot, heading back toward her tent.

tʃæptɝ sɪkstin

CHAPTER 16

ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ "aɪm kjʊɹiəs tə hɪɹ ðə nɑvəs spik. tɛl mi, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, haʊ wəd juv hændəl ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən?"

In the White Tower "I'm curious to hear the novice speak. Tell me, Egwene al'Vere, how would you have handled the situation?"

ɛɡwin lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə boʊl ə ʃɛlz, tu-lɛɡəd stil nʌtkɹækɝ ɪn wʌn hænd, ə bʌlbəs wɔlnʌɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɛni ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹɛzən hæɾ ədʒɹɛs hɝ. ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk ðəɾ ətɛndɪŋ ðə θɹi waɪts wəd tɝn aʊt tə bi ənʌðɝ weɪst ə taɪm.

Egwene looked up from the bowl of shells, two-legged steel nutcracker in one hand, a bulbous walnut in the other. It was the first time any of the Aes Sedai present had addressed her. She had begun to think that attending the three Whites would turn out to be another waste of time.

ði æftɝnunz loʊkeɪʃən wɑz ə smɔl ɪnsɛt bælkəni ɑn ðə θɝd lɛvəl ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. sɪɾɝz kəd dɪmæn ɹumz wɪð nɑɾ oʊnli fʊl wɪndoʊz, bʌt bælkəniz əz wɛl, sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɑz ənkɑmən - ðoʊ nɑɾ ənhɝd-ʌv - fəɹ ɹɛɡjəlɝ sɪstɝz. ðɪs wʌn wɑz ʃeɪp laɪk ə smɔl tɝət, wɪð ə stɝɾi stoʊn wɔl ɹʌnɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɹɪm ɪn ə kɝv, ə sɪməlɝ stoʊn hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ði aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ əbʌv. ðəɹ wɑz dʒɛnɝəs speɪs bɪtwin ðə tu ən ðə vju wɑz kwaɪt bjuɾəfəl, istwɝɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ hɪlz ðəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli klaɪm tə kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ. ðə dæɡɝ ɪtsɛlf maɪɾ əv bɪn dɪstənli vɪzəbəl ɑn ə klɪɹ deɪ.

The afternoon's location was a small inset balcony on the third level of the White Tower. Sitters could demand rooms with not only full windows, but balconies as well, something that was uncommon - though not unheard-of - for regular sisters. This one was shaped like a small turret, with a sturdy stone wall running around the rim in a curve, a similar stone hanging from the outcropping above. There was generous space between the two and the view was quite beautiful, eastward across the rising hills that eventually climbed to Kinslayer's Dagger. The Dagger itself might have been distantly visible on a clear day.

ə kul bɹiz blu əkɹɔs ðə bælkəni, ən ðɪs haɪ ʌp ɪt wɑz fɹɛʃ ən ənsʌlid baɪ ðə stɪŋk ə ðə sɪɾi bɪloʊ. ə sɪnwəs pɛɹ ə stɪklʃɑɹps - wɪð ðɛɹ θɹi-pɹɔŋ livz ən klɪŋɪŋ vaɪnz -  ɡɹu ɑn itʃ saɪɾ ə ðə bælkəni, ðɛɹ kɹipɪŋ tɛnʒɹəlz kʌvɝɪŋ ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə stoʊnwɝk ən meɪkɪŋ ɪt lʊk ɔlmoʊs laɪk ə dip fɔɹəst ɹuən. ðə plæns wɝ mɔɹ ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən ðən ɛɡwin wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹɾɝz ʌv ə waɪt, bʌt fɛɹən wɑz ɹipɔɹɾəd tə bi ə ʃeɪɾ ɑn ðə veɪn saɪd. ʃi pɹɑbli laɪkt ɪt ðəɾ əɹ bælkəni wɑz soʊ dɪstɪŋktɪv, ivən ɪf pɹoʊɾəkɑl ɹikwaɪɝɾ əɹ tə kip ðə vaɪnz pɹun əz tə nɑt mɑɹ ðə ɡlimɪŋ pɹoʊfaɪl ə ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf.

A cool breeze blew across the balcony, and this high up it was fresh and unsullied by the stink of the city below. A sinuous pair of sticklesharps - with their three-pronged leaves and clinging vines -  grew on each side of the balcony, their creeping tendrils covering the inside of the stonework and making it look almost like a deep forest ruin. The plants were more ornamentation than Egwene would have expected in the quarters of a White, but Ferane was reported to be a shade on the vain side. She probably liked it that her balcony was so distinctive, even if protocol required her to keep the vines pruned as to not mar the gleaming profile of the Tower itself.

ðə θɹi waɪts sæɾ ɪn wɪkɝ tʃɛɹz əɾ ə loʊ teɪbəl. ɛɡwin sæt bɪfɔɹ əm ɑn ə wɪkɝ stul, bæk tə ði oʊpən ɛɹ, dɪnaɪd ðə vju əz ʃi kɹæk nʌts fəɹ ði ʌðɝz. ɛni nʌmbɝ ə sɝvəns əɹ kɪtʃən wɝkɝz cʊɾə dʌn ðə wɝk. bʌt ðɪs wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ðət sɪstɝz faʊn tə fɪl ðə taɪm ə nɑvəsɪz hum ðeɪ θɔt maɪt bi laʊnʒɪŋ əbaʊt tu mʌtʃ.

The three Whites sat in wicker chairs at a low table. Egwene sat before them on a wicker stool, back to the open air, denied the view as she cracked nuts for the others. Any number of servants or kitchen workers could have done the work. But this was the sort of thing that sisters found to fill the time of novices whom they thought might be lounging about too much.

ɛɡwin hæd θɔt ðət kɹækɪŋ ðə wɔlnʌts wɑz dʒʌst ə pɹitɛns. æftɝ biɪŋ ɪɡnɔɹd fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ən aʊɝ, ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə wʌndɝ, bʌɾ ɔl θɹi wɝ lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ naʊ. ʃi ʃʊdn əv daʊɾɪd əɹ ɪnstɪŋks.

Egwene had thought that cracking the walnuts was just a pretense. After being ignored for the better part of an hour, she had begun to wonder, but all three were looking at her now. She shouldn't have doubted her instincts.

fɛɹən hæd ðə kɑpɝi skɪn ʌv ə dəmɑni, ən ə tɛmpɹəmən tə mætʃ, ɑd fəɹ ə waɪt. ʃi wɑz ʃɔɹt, wɪð ən æpəl-ʃeɪp feɪs ən dɑɹk, lʌstʃɹəs hɛɹ. hɝ ɑbɝn dʒɹɛs wɑz fɪlmi bʌt disənt wɪð ə waɪd waɪt sæʃ ət ðə weɪs tə mætʃ əɹ ʃɔl, wɪtʃ ʃi wɑz kɝənli wɛɹɪŋ. ðə dʒɹɛs dɪdn læk fəɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ən ðə fæbɹɪk dɪd sim ən ɪndəkeɪʃən, pɝhæps ɪntɛnʃənəl, ʌv əɹ dəmɑni hɛɹəɾədʒ.

Ferane had the coppery skin of a Domani, and a temperament to match, odd for a White. She was short, with an apple-shaped face and dark, lustrous hair. Her auburn dress was filmy but decent with a wide white sash at the waist to match her shawl, which she was currently wearing. The dress didn't lack for embroidery, and the fabric did seem an indication, perhaps intentional, of her Domani heritage.

ði ʌðɝ tu, mijɑsi ən tɛzən, boʊθ wɔɹ waɪt, əz ɪf ðeɪ fɪɹd ðət dʒɹɛsəz ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ kʌlɝz wɝ ə bɪtʃɹeɪəl ə ðɛɹ ədʒɑ. ðət noʊʃən wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ kɑmən əmʌŋ ɔl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. tɛzən wɑz ə tæɹɑbənɝ, wɪð əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ ɪn biɾɪd bɹeɪdz. ðə bidz wɝ waɪɾ ən ɡoʊld, ən ðeɪ fɹeɪmd ə nɛɹoʊ feɪs ðət lʊkt əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn pɪntʃt ət tɑp ən bɑɾəm ən pʊld. ʃi ɔlweɪz lʊkt wɝiɾ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ. ðoʊ pɝhæps ðət wɑz dʒʌs ðə taɪmz. laɪt nu ðeɪ ɔl hæɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə wɝi oʊvɝ.

The other two, Miyasi and Tesan, both wore white, as if they feared that dresses of any other colors were a betrayal of their Ajah. That notion was becoming more and more common among all of the Aes Sedai. Tesan was a Taraboner, with her dark hair in beaded braids. The beads were white and gold, and they framed a narrow face that looked as if it had been pinched at top and bottom and pulled. She always looked worried about something. Though perhaps that was just the times. Light knew they all had a great deal to worry over.

mijɑsi wɑz mɔɹ kɑm, hɝ hɛd tɑp baɪ aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɪn ə bʌn. hɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs bɪtʃɹeɪd nʌn ə ðə mɛni jɪɹz ðət ʃi mʌst əv sin fəɹ əɹ hɛɹ tə sɪlvɝ soʊ fʊli. ʃi wɑz tɔl ən plʌmp, ən ʃi pɹəfɝɾ əɹ wɔlnʌts ʃɛl vɛɹi pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli. noʊ fɹæɡməns əɹ bɹoʊkən pisəz ə nʌt fəɹ hɝ, oʊnli fʊl hævz. ɛɡwin kɛɹfəli pɹaɪd wʌn fɹəm ðə ʃɛl ʃi hæd kɹækt, ðən hændəɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ; ðə smɔl bɹaʊn lʌmp wɑz ɹɪŋkəld ən ɹɪdʒd, laɪk ðə bɹeɪn ʌv ə taɪni ænəməl.

Miyasi was more calm, her head topped by iron-gray hair in a bun. Her Aes Sedai face betrayed none of the many years that she must have seen for her hair to silver so fully. She was tall and plump, and she preferred her walnuts shelled very particularly. No fragments or broken pieces of nut for her, only full halves. Egwene carefully pried one from the shell she had cracked, then handed it over; the small brown lump was wrinkled and ridged, like the brain of a tiny animal.

"wʌt wɑz ɪt jə æskt, fɛɹən?" ɛɡwin æskt, kɹækɪŋ ənʌðɝ wɔlnʌɾ ən dɪskɑɹɾɪŋ ðə ʃɛl ɪn ə peɪl əɾ əɹ fit.

"What was it you asked, Ferane?" Egwene asked, cracking another walnut and discarding the shell in a pail at her feet.

ðə waɪt bɛɹli fɹaʊn əɾ ɛɡwinz ɪmpɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɑns. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɡɹoʊɪŋ əkʌstəm tə ðə fæk ðət ðɪs "nɑvəs" sɛldəm æktəɾ əɹ pɹəzum steɪʃən. "aɪ æskt," fɛɹən sɛd kuli, "wʌt jə wʊɾə dʌn ɪn ði æmɪɝlɪnz pleɪs. kənsɪɾɝ ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə jəɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən. jə noʊ ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən əz bɪn ɹibɔɹn ən jə noʊ ðət ðə taʊɝ mʌs kəntʃɹoʊl ɪm ɪn ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl tə pɹəsid. haʊ wəd jə hændəl hɪm?"

The White barely frowned at Egwene's improper response. They were all growing accustomed to the fact that this "novice" seldom acted her presumed station. "I asked," Ferane said coolly, "what you would have done in the Amyrlin's place. Consider this part of your instruction. You know that the Dragon has been reborn and you know that the Tower must control him in order for the Last Battle to proceed. How would you handle him?"

ə kjʊɹiəs kwɛstʃən. ɪt dɪdn saʊn mʌtʃ laɪk "ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən." bʌt fɛɹənz toʊn dɪdn meɪk ɪt saʊn laɪk ən ɔfɝ tə kəmpleɪn əbaʊɾ ɪleɪɾə iðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ kəntɛmp fəɹ ɛɡwin ɪn ðət vɔɪs.

A curious question. It didn't sound much like "instruction." But Ferane's tone didn't make it sound like an offer to complain about Elaida either. There was too much contempt for Egwene in that voice.

ði ʌðɝ tu waɪts ɹɪmeɪn kwaɪət. fɛɹən wɑz ə sɪɾɝ, ən ðeɪ dɪfɝd tə hɝ.

The other two Whites remained quiet. Ferane was a Sitter, and they deferred to her.

ʃiz hɝd haʊ ɔfən aɪ mɛnʃən ɪleɪɾəz feɪljɝ wɪð ɹænd, ɛɡwin θɔt, lʊkɪŋ ɪndə fɛɹənz stili blæk aɪz. soʊ. ə tɛst, ɪz ɪt? ðɪs wəɾ əv tə bi hændəl vɛɹi kɛɹfəli.

She's heard how often I mention Elaida's failure with Rand, Egwene thought, looking into Ferane's steely black eyes. So. A test, is it? This would have to be handled very carefully.

ɛɡwin ɹitʃt fəɹ ənʌðɝ wɔlnʌt. "fɝst, aɪ wəd sɛn ə ɡɹup ə sɪstɝz tə hɪz hoʊm vɪlədʒ."

Egwene reached for another walnut. "First, I would send a group of sisters to his home village."

fɛɹən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "tə ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾ ɪz fæmli?"

Ferane raised an eyebrow. "To intimidate his family?"

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "tə ɪntɛɹəɡeɪt ðɛm. hu ɪz ðɪs dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ɪz i ə mæn ə tɛmpɝ, ə mæn ə pæʃənz? əɹ ɪz i ə kɑm mæn, kɛɹfəl ən kɔʃəs? wɑz i ðə taɪp tə spɛn taɪm əloʊn ɪn ðə filz, əɹ dɪɾ i meɪk kwɪk fɹɛnz ə ði ʌðɝ juðz? wəd jə bi mɔɹ laɪkli tə faɪn ɪm ɪn ə tævɝn əɹ ə wɝkʃɑp?"

"Of course not," Egwene said. "To interrogate them. Who is this Dragon Reborn? Is he a man of temper, a man of passions? Or is he a calm man, careful and cautious? Was he the type to spend time alone in the fields, or did he make quick friends of the other youths? Would you be more likely to find him in a tavern or a workshop?"

"bʌt jə ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ hɪm," tɛzən paɪpt ɪn.

"But you already know him," Tesan piped in.

"aɪ du," ɛɡwin sɛd, kɹækɪŋ ðə wɔlnʌt. "bʌt wi wɝ spikɪŋ ʌv ə haɪpəθɛɾəkəl sɪtʃueɪʃən."

"I do," Egwene said, cracking the walnut. "But we were speaking of a hypothetical situation."

bɛs jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld, aɪ noʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn pɝsənəli. əz noʊbɑdi ɛls ɪn ðɪs taʊɝ dʌz.

Best you remember that in the real world, I know the Dragon Reborn personally. As nobody else in this Tower does.

"lɛɾ əs əsum ðət jə ɑɹ ju," fɛɹən sɛd. "æn ðət hiz ɹænd ælθɹ, jəɹ tʃaɪldhʊd fɹɛnd."

"Let us assume that you are you," Ferane said. "And that he is Rand al'Thor, your childhood friend."

"vɛɹi wɛl."

"Very well."

"tɛl mi," fɛɹən sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. "ʌv ðə taɪps ə mɛn jə lɪstəd dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ, wɪtʃ bɛs fɪts ðɪs ɹænd ælθɹ?"

"Tell me," Ferane said, leaning forward. "Of the types of men you listed just before, which best fits this Rand al'Thor?"

ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ɔl ə ðɛm," ʃi sɛd, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ə fɹæɡməntɪd wɔlnʌɾ ɪndə ə smɔl boʊl wɪð ʌðɝz. mijɑsi wʊdn tʌtʃ ɪt, bʌt ði ʌðɝ tu wɝn soʊ pɪki. "ɪf aɪ wɝ mi ən ðə dʒɹæɡən wɝ ɹænd, aɪd noʊ hɪm tə bi ə ɹæʃənəl pɝsən, fəɹ ə mæn - ɪf sʌmwʌt bʊlhɛɾɪd ət taɪmz. wɛl, moʊst ə ðə taɪm. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli, aɪd noʊ hɪm tə bi ə ɡʊd mæn ət hɑɹt. ən soʊ, maɪ nɛkst stɛp wəd bi tə sɛn sɪstɝz tə hɪm tə ɔfɝ ɡaɪɾəns."

Egwene hesitated. "All of them," she said, dropping a fragmented walnut into a small bowl with others. Miyasi wouldn't touch it, but the other two weren't so picky. "If I were me and the Dragon were Rand, I'd know him to be a rational person, for a man - if somewhat bullheaded at times. Well, most of the time. More importantly, I'd know him to be a good man at heart. And so, my next step would be to send sisters to him to offer guidance."

"æn ɪf i ɹɪdʒɛktɪd ðɛm?" fɛɹən æskt.

"And if he rejected them?" Ferane asked.

"ðɛn aɪd sɛn spaɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ænd wɑtʃ tə si ɪf hiz tʃeɪnʒd fɹəm ðə mæn aɪ wʌns nu."

"Then I'd send spies," Egwene said, "and watch to see if he has changed from the man I once knew."

"ænd waɪl jə weɪɾəd ən spaɪd, hi wəd tɛɹɝaɪz ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd, ɹikɪŋ hævək ən bɹɪŋɪŋ ɑɹmiz tə hɪz bænɝ."

"And while you waited and spied, he would terrorize the countryside, wreaking havoc and bringing armies to his banner."

"æn ɪz ðət nɑt wʌt wi wɑn ɪm tə du?" ɛɡwin æskt. "aɪ doʊn bɪliv i cʊɾə bɪn pɹɪvɛntɪd fɹəm teɪkɪŋ kælændɝ, ʃəd wɪv wɑntəɾ ɪm tə bi. hiz mænədʒ tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ tə kɛɹhin, junaɪt tiɹ ən ɪljən bɪniθ wʌn ɹulɝ, ən pɹəzuməbli hæz ɡeɪn ðə feɪvɝ ʌv ændɝ əz wɛl."

"And is that not what we want him to do?" Egwene asked. "I don't believe he could have been prevented from taking Callandor, should we have wanted him to be. He has managed to restore order to Cairhien, unite Tear and Illian beneath one ruler, and presumably has gained the favor of Andor as well."

"nɑt tə mɛnʃən səbʒəɡeɪtɪŋ ðoʊz il," mijɑsi sɛd, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ə hændfʊl ə nʌts.

"Not to mention subjugating those Aiel," Miyasi said, reaching for a handful of nuts.

ɛɡwin kɑɾ əɹ wɪð ə ʃɑɹp ɡeɪz. "noʊbɑdi səbʒəɡeɪts ði il. ɹænd ɡeɪn ðɛɹ ɹɪspɛkt. aɪ wɑz wɪð ɪm ət ðə taɪm."

Egwene caught her with a sharp gaze. "Nobody subjugates the Aiel. Rand gained their respect. I was with him at the time."

mijɑsi fɹoʊz, hæn pɑɹtweɪ tə ðə boʊl ə nʌtmiəts. ʃi ʃʊk hɝsɛlf, bɹeɪkɪŋ ɛɡwinz ɡeɪz, ɡɹæbɪŋ ðə boʊl ən ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ bæk tə hɝ tʃɛɹ. ə kul bɹiz blu əkɹɔs ðə bælkəni, ɹʌslɪŋ ðə vaɪnz, wɪtʃ fɛɹən hæd kəmpleɪnd wɝ nɑt ɡɹinɪŋ ðɪs spɹɪŋ laɪk ðeɪ ʃʊd. ɛɡwin ɹɪtɝn tə ʃɛlɪŋ wɔlnʌts.

Miyasi froze, hand partway to the bowl of nutmeats. She shook herself, breaking Egwene's gaze, grabbing the bowl and retreating back to her chair. A cool breeze blew across the balcony, rustling the vines, which Ferane had complained were not greening this spring like they should. Egwene returned to shelling walnuts.

"ɪt simz," fɛɹən sɛd, "ðæt jə wəd sɪmpli lɛɾ ɪm saʊ keɪɑs əz i sɔ fɪt."

"It seems," Ferane said, "that you would simply let him sow chaos as he saw fit."

"ɹæn ælθɹ ɪz laɪk ə ɹɪvɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "kɑm ən plæsəd wən nɑɾ ædʒəteɪɾəd, bʌɾ ə fjʊɹiəs ən dɛdli kɝənt wən skwiz tu taɪtli. wʌɾ ɪleɪɾə dɪd tə hɪm wɑz ði ɪkwɪvələn ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs ðə meɪnɛðɹəndʒɹɛl θɹu ə kænjən oʊnli tu fit waɪd. weɪɾɪŋ tə dɪskʌvɝ ə mænz tɛmpɹəmən ɪz nɑt fulɪʃ, nɔɹ ɪz ɪɾ ə saɪn ʌv wiknəs. æktɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɪz lunəsi, ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ dɪzɝv ðə tɛmpəst ɪt ɹaɪld ʌp."

"Rand al'Thor is like a river," Egwene said. "Calm and placid when not agitated, but a furious and deadly current when squeezed too tightly. What Elaida did to him was the equivalent of trying to force the Manetherendrelle through a canyon only two feet wide. Waiting to discover a man's temperament is not foolish, nor is it a sign of weakness. Acting without information is lunacy, and the White Tower deserved the tempest it riled up."

"pɝhæps," fɛɹən sɛd. "bʌt juv stɪl nɑt toʊl mi haʊ jə wəd dil wɪð ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən, wʌns jəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən wɑz kəlɛktəɾ ən ðə taɪm fəɹ weɪɾɪŋ hæd pæst." fɛɹən wɑz noʊn fəɹ əɹ tɛmpɝ, bʌɾ ət ðə moʊmən əɹ vɔɪs hɛl ðə koʊlnəs kɑmən əmʌŋ waɪts. ɪt wɑz ðə koʊlnəs ʌv wʌn u spoʊk wɪθaʊɾ ɪmoʊʃən, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt lɑdʒɪk wɪθaʊt tɑlɝeɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪnfluənsɪz.

"Perhaps," Ferane said. "But you have still not told me how you would deal with the situation, once your information was collected and the time for waiting had passed." Ferane was known for her temper, but at the moment her voice held the coldness common among Whites. It was the coldness of one who spoke without emotion, thinking about logic without tolerating outside influences.

ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə bɛst weɪ tə əpɹoʊtʃ pɹɑbləmz. pipəl wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑmplɛks ðən ə sɛɾ ə ɹulz əɹ nʌmbɝz. ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪm fəɹ lɑdʒɪk, tʃɹu, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɔlsoʊ ə taɪm fəɹ ɪmoʊʃən.

It was not the best way to approach problems. People were much more complex than a set of rules or numbers. There was a time for logic, true, but there was also a time for emotion.

ɹænd wɑz ə pɹɑbləm ʃi hædn əlaʊd hɝsɛlf tə dwɛl ɑn - ʃi niɾəd tə dil wɪð wʌn pɹɑbləm əɾ ə taɪm. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɔlsoʊ mʌtʃ tə bi sɛd fəɹ plænɪŋ əhɛd. ɪf ʃi dɪdn kənsɪɾɝ haʊ tə dil wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ʃiɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli faɪn hɝsɛlf ɪn əz bæɾ ə sɪtʃueɪʃən əz ɪleɪɾə.

Rand was a problem she hadn't allowed herself to dwell on - she needed to deal with one problem at a time. But there was also much to be said for planning ahead. If she didn't consider how to deal with the Dragon Reborn, she'd eventually find herself in as bad a situation as Elaida.

hi hæd tʃeɪnʒd fɹəm ðə mæn ʃi hæd noʊn. ən jɛt ðə sidz ə pɝsənælɪɾi wɪðɪn ɪm mʌs bi ðə seɪm. ʃid sin ɪz ɹeɪdʒ dʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ mʌnθs tʃɹævlɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ɪndə ði il weɪst. ðət hædn ɔfən kʌm aʊt dʊɹɪŋ ɪz tʃaɪldhʊd, bʌt ʃi kəd si naʊ ðəɾ ɪt mʌst əv bɪn lɝkɪŋ. ɪt wɑzn ðəɾ i hæd sʌɾənli dɪvɛləpt ə tɛmpɝ; ɪt wɑz sɪmpli ðət nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz hæɾ ʌpsɛt hɪm.

He had changed from the man she had known. And yet the seeds of personality within him must be the same. She'd seen his rage during their months traveling together into the Aiel Waste. That hadn't often come out during his childhood, but she could see now that it must have been lurking. It wasn't that he had suddenly developed a temper; it was simply that nothing in the Two Rivers had upset him.

dʊɹɪŋ ðə mʌnθs ʃid tʃɹævəld wɪð hɪm, hid sim tə hɑɹɾən wɪð itʃ stɛp. hi wɑz ʌndɝ ɪkstʃɹɔɹɾənɛɹi pɹɛʃɝz. haʊ dɪd wʌn dil wɪð sətʃ ə mæn? ʃi fɹæŋkli hæd noʊ aɪdiə.

During the months she'd traveled with him, he'd seemed to harden with each step. He was under extraordinary pressures. How did one deal with such a man? She frankly had no idea.

bʌt ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɑzn əbaʊt wʌt tə də wɪð ɹænd, nɑt ɹɪli. ɪt wɑz əbaʊt fɛɹən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dətɝmən wʌt kaɪndə wʊmən ɛɡwin wɑz.

But this conversation wasn't about what to do with Rand, not really. It was about Ferane trying to determine what kind of woman Egwene was.

"ɹæn ælθɹ siz hɪmsɛlf əz ən ɛmpɝɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn aɪ səpoʊz hiz wʌn, naʊ. hɪl ɹiæk pʊɹli ɪf i θɪŋks hiz biɪŋ pʊʃt əɹ ʃʌvd ɪn ɛni pɝtɪkjəlɝ dɝɛkʃən. ɪf aɪ wɝ tə dil wɪð hɪm, aɪ wəd sɛn ə dɛləɡeɪʃən tə ɑnɝ hɪm."

"Rand al'Thor sees himself as an emperor," Egwene said. "And I suppose he is one, now. He will react poorly if he thinks he is being pushed or shoved in any particular direction. If I were to deal with him, I would send a delegation to honor him."

"ə lævɪʃ pɹəsɛʃən?" fɛɹən æskt.

"A lavish procession?" Ferane asked.

"noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌt nɑɾ ə θɹɛdbɛɹ wʌn iðɝ. ə ɡɹup ə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ, lɛd baɪ ə ɡɹeɪ, əkʌmpənid baɪ ə ɡɹin ən ə blu. hi vjuz ðə blu feɪvɝəbli kəz ə pæst əsoʊsieɪʃənz, ən ɡɹinz ɑɹ ɔfən pɝsivd əz ði ɑpəzəts tə ɹɛdz, ə sʌɾəl ɪndəkeɪʃən ðət wəɹ wɪlɪŋ tə wɝk wɪð ɪm ɹæðɝ ðən dʒɛntəl hɪm. eɪ ɡɹeɪ kəz ɪt wəd bi ɪkspɛktəd, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ kəz ɪf ə ɡɹeɪ ɪz sɛnt, ðən ɪt minz nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz, nɑɾ ɑɹmiz, wɪl fɑloʊ."

"No," Egwene said. "But not a threadbare one either. A group of three Aes Sedai, led by a Gray, accompanied by a Green and a Blue. He views the Blue favorably because of past associations, and Greens are often perceived as the opposites to Reds, a subtle indication that we are willing to work with him rather than gentle him. A Gray because it would be expected, but also because if a Gray is sent, then it means negotiations, not armies, will follow."

"ɡʊd lɑdʒɪk," tɛzən sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ.

"Good logic," Tesan said, nodding.

fɛɹən wɑz nɑt soʊ izəli kənvɪnst. "dɛləɡeɪʃənz laɪk ðɪs wʌn əv feɪld ɪn ðə pæst. aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ ɪleɪɾəz oʊn dɛləɡeɪʃən wɑz lɛd baɪ ə ɡɹeɪ."

Ferane was not so easily convinced. "Delegations like this one have failed in the past. I believe that Elaida's own delegation was led by a Gray."

"jɛs, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾəz dɛləɡeɪʃən wɑz fʌndəmɛntəli flɔd," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Yes, but Elaida's delegation was fundamentally flawed," Egwene said.

"ænd waɪ ɪz ðæt?"

"And why is that?"

"waɪ, kəz ɪt wɑz sɛn baɪ ə ɹɛd, ʌv kɔɹs," ɛɡwin sɛd, kɹækɪŋ ə nʌt. "aɪ hæv tʃɹʌbəl siɪŋ ðə lɑdʒɪk ɪn ɹeɪzɪŋ ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ tə æmɪɝlɪn dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. dʌzn ðət sim dɛstɪn tə kɹieɪɾ ænəmɑsəɾi bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə taʊɝ?"

"Why, because it was sent by a Red, of course," Egwene said, cracking a nut. "I have trouble seeing the logic in raising a member of the Red Ajah to Amyrlin during the days of the Dragon Reborn. Doesn't that seem destined to create animosity between him and the Tower?"

"wʌn maɪt seɪ," fɛɹən kaʊntɝd, "ðæɾ ə ɹɛɾ ɪz niɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ðiz tʃɹʌbəl taɪmz, fəɹ ðə ɹɛɾ ɑɹ ðə moʊst ɪkspɪɹiənst ət dilɪŋ wɪð mɛn u kən tʃænəl."

"One might say," Ferane countered, "that a Red is needed during these troubled times, for the Red are the most experienced at dealing with men who can channel."

" 'dilɪŋ' wɪð ɪz dɪfɹən fɹəm 'wɝkɪŋ' wɪð," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ʃəd nɑɾ əv bɪn lɛf tə ɹʌn fɹi, bʌt sɪns wən əz ðə waɪt taʊɝ bɪn ɪn ðə bɪznəs ə kɪdnæpɪŋ ən fɔɹsɪŋ pipəl tə əɹ wɪl? ɑɹ wi nɑt noʊn əz ðə moʊst sʌɾəl ən kɛɹfəl ʌv ɔl pipəl? də wi nɑt pɹaɪɾ aʊɝsɛlvz ɑn biɪŋ eɪbəl tə meɪk ʌðɝz də əz ðeɪ ʃʊd, ɔl ðə waɪl lɛɾɪŋ əm θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ aɪdiə? wən ɪn ðə pæst əv wi lɑkt kɪŋz ɪn bɑksəz ən biɾən əm fəɹ dɪsəbiɾiəns?

" 'Dealing' with is different from 'working' with," Egwene said. "The Dragon Reborn should not have been left to run free, but since when has the White Tower been in the business of kidnapping and forcing people to our will? Are we not known as the most subtle and careful of all people? Do we not pride ourselves on being able to make others do as they should, all the while letting them think it was their idea? When in the past have we locked kings in boxes and beaten them for disobedience?

waɪ naʊ - ʌv ɔl ðə taɪmz ʌndɝ ðə laɪt - hæv wi fɔɹseɪkən əɹ faɪn pɹæktəs ən bɪkʌm sɪmpəl fʊtpædz ɪnstɛd?"

Why now - of all the times under the Light - have we forsaken our fine practice and become simple footpads instead?"

fɛɹən səlɛktəɾ ə wɔlnʌt. ði ʌðɝ tu waɪts wɝ ʃɛɹɪŋ ən ənsɛɾəld lʊk. "ðɛɹ ɪz sɛns ɪn wʌt jə seɪ," ðə sɪɾɝ faɪnəli ədmɪɾəd.

Ferane selected a walnut. The other two Whites were sharing an unsettled look. "There is sense in what you say," the Sitter finally admitted.

ɛɡwin sɛɾ əsaɪd ðə nʌtkɹækɝ. "ɹæn ælθɹ ɪz ə ɡʊd mæn, ɪn ɪz hɑɹt, bʌɾ i nidz ɡaɪɾəns. ðiz deɪz ɑɹ wən wi ʃʊɾə bɪn əɾ əɹ moʊst sʌɾəl. hi ʃʊɾə bɪn lɛd tə tʃɹʌst ɛɛs sədaɪ əbʌv ɔl ʌðɝz, tə ɹɪlaɪ ɑn əɹ kaʊnsəl. hi ʃʊɾə bɪn ʃoʊn ðə wɪzdəm ɪn lɪsnɪŋ. ɪnstɛd, hiz bɪn ʃoʊn ðət wɪl tʃɹiɾ ɪm laɪk ən ənɹuli tʃaɪld. ɪf hiz wʌn, hi kænɑt bi əlaʊd tə θɪŋk wi ɹəɡɑɹɾ ɪm ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ. kəz ʌv əɹ bʌŋɡəlɪŋ, hiz teɪkən səm ɛɛs sədaɪ kæptɪv, ən əz əlaʊd stɪl ʌðɝz tə bi bɑndəd tə ðoʊz æʃəmən ə hɪz."

Egwene set aside the nutcracker. "Rand al'Thor is a good man, in his heart, but he needs guidance. These days are when we should have been at our most subtle. He should have been led to trust Aes Sedai above all others, to rely on our counsel. He should have been shown the wisdom in listening. Instead, he has been shown that we will treat him like an unruly child. If he is one, he cannot be allowed to think we regard him in such a way. Because of our bungling, he has taken some Aes Sedai captive, and has allowed still others to be bonded to those Asha'man of his."

fɛɹən sæɾ ʌp stɪfli. "bɛs nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðəɾ ətʃɹɑsəɾi."

Ferane sat up stiffly. "Best not to mention that atrocity."

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?" tɛzən sɛd, ʃɑkt, hæn ɹeɪz tə hɝ bɹɛst. səm waɪts nɛvɝ sim tə peɪ ətɛnʃən tə ðə wɝld ɝaʊn ðɛm. "fɛɹən? dɪd jə noʊ ʌv ðɪs?"

"What is this?" Tesan said, shocked, hand raised to her breast. Some Whites never seemed to pay attention to the world around them. "Ferane? Did you know of this?"

fɛɹən dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd.

Ferane didn't respond.

"aɪv . . . hɝd ðɪs ɹumɝ," sɛd staʊt mijɑsi. "ɪf ɪts tʃɹu, ðən sʌmθɪŋ mʌs bi dʌn."

"I've . . . heard this rumor," said stout Miyasi. "If it is true, then something must be done."

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ənfɔɹtʃənətli, wi kænɑt foʊkəs ɑn ælθɹ ɹaɪt naʊ."

"Yes," Egwene said. "Unfortunately, we cannot focus on al'Thor right now."

"hi ɪz ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst pɹɑbləm feɪsɪŋ ðə wɝld," pɪntʃ-feɪs tɛzən sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. "wi mʌs dil wɪð ɪm fɝst."

"He is the greatest problem facing the world," pinch-faced Tesan said, leaning forward. "We must deal with him first."

"noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ ɪʃuz."

"No," Egwene said. "There are other issues."

mijɑsi fɹaʊnd. "wɪð ðə læs bæɾəl ɪmpɛndɪŋ, aɪ kæn si ɛni ʌðɝ ɪʃuz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns."

Miyasi frowned. "With the Last Battle impending, I can't see any other issues of importance."

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɪn dilɪŋ wɪð ɹænd naʊ, wid bi laɪk ə fɑɹmɝ, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪz wæɡən ən wɝiɪŋ ðət ðəɹ ɑɹən ɛni ɡʊdz ɪn ðə bɛd fəɹ ɪm tə sɛl - bʌɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə fæk ðəɾ ɪz æksəl ɪz kɹækt. fɪl ðə bɛd bɪfɔɹ ɪts taɪm, ən jəl dʒʌs bɹeɪk ðə wæɡən ən bi wɝs ɔf ðən wən jə stɑɹɾəd."

Egwene shook her head. "In dealing with Rand now, we'd be like a farmer, looking at his wagon and worrying that there aren't any goods in the bed for him to sell - but ignoring the fact that his axle is cracked. Fill the bed before it is time, and you'll just break the wagon and be worse off than when you started."

"ænd wʌt, ɪɡzækli, ɑɹ jə ɪmplaɪɪŋ?" tɛzən dɪmændəd.

"And what, exactly, are you implying?" Tesan demanded.

ɛɡwin lʊk bæk ət fɛɹən.

Egwene looked back at Ferane.

"aɪ si," fɛɹən sɛd. "ju ɑɹ ɹɪfɝɪŋ tə ðə dɪvɪʒən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"I see," Ferane said. "You are referring to the division in the White Tower."

"kæn ə kɹæk stoʊn bi ə ɡʊd faʊndeɪʃən fəɹ ə bɪldɪŋ?" ɛɡwin æskt. "kæn ə fɹeɪd ɹoʊp hoʊld ə pænɪki hɔɹs? haʊ kən wi, ɪn əɹ kɝən steɪt, hoʊp tə mænədʒ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf?"

"Can a cracked stone be a good foundation for a building?" Egwene asked. "Can a frayed rope hold a panicky horse? How can we, in our current state, hope to manage the Dragon Reborn himself?"

fɛɹən sɛd, "waɪ, ðɛn, dʒju kəntɪnju tə ɛnfɔɹs ðə dɪvɪʒən baɪ ɪnsɪstɪŋ ðət jə ɑɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit? jə dɪfaɪ jəɹ oʊn lɑdʒɪk."

Ferane said, "Why, then, do you continue to enforce the division by insisting that you are the Amyrlin Seat? You defy your own logic."

"æn ɹɪnaʊnsɪŋ maɪ kleɪm ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wəd mɛn ðə taʊɝ?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"And renouncing my claim on the Amyrlin Seat would mend the Tower?" Egwene asked.

"ɪt wəd hɛlp."

"It would help."

ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "lɛɾ əs əsum, fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðət baɪ ɹɪnaʊnsɪŋ maɪ kleɪm, aɪ kəd pɝsweɪd ðə ɹɛbəl fækʃən tə ɹidʒɔɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən æksɛpt ɪleɪɾəz liɾɝʃɪp." ʃi ɹeɪz ði aɪbɹaʊ fɝðɝ, ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ haʊ laɪkli ʃi θɔt ðət wɑz. "wʊd ðə dɪvɪʒənz bi hild?"

Egwene raised an eyebrow. "Let us assume, for a moment, that by renouncing my claim, I could persuade the rebel faction to rejoin the White Tower and accept Elaida's leadership." She raised the eyebrow further, indicating how likely she thought that was. "Would the divisions be healed?"

"ju dʒʌst sɛd ðeɪ wəd bi," tɛzən sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"You just said they would be," Tesan said, frowning.

"oʊ?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "wʊd sɪstɝz stɑp skɝiɪŋ θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz, fɹaɪɾənd tə bi əloʊn?

"Oh?" Egwene said. "Would sisters stop scurrying through the hallways, frightened to be alone?

wəd ɡɹups ʌv wɪmən fɹəm dɪfɹən ədʒəz stɑp ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ wɪð hɑstɪləɾi wən ðeɪ pæs ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz? wɪð ɔl du ɹɪspɛkt, wəd wi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fil ðə nid tə wɛɹ əɹ ʃɔlz əɾ ɔl taɪmz tə ɹiɪnfɔɹs u wəɹ ən wɛɹ əɹ əlidʒəns ɪz?"

Would groups of women from different Ajahs stop regarding each other with hostility when they pass in the hallways? With all due respect, would we no longer feel the need to wear our shawls at all times to reinforce who we are and where our allegiance is?"

fɛɹən ɡlæns daʊn, bɹifli, əɾ əɹ waɪt-fɹɪnd ʃɔl.

Ferane glanced down, briefly, at her white-fringed shawl.

ɛɡwin lin fɔɹwɝd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ. "ʃʊɹli ju, ʌv ɔl wɪmən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, kən si ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə ði ədʒəz wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. wi nid wɪmən wɪð dɪfɹən skɪlz ən ɪntʃɹəsts tə ɡæðɝ ɪndə ədʒəz. bʌt dʌz ɪt meɪk sɛns fəɹ əs tə ɹəfjuz tə wɝk təɡɛðɝ?"

Egwene leaned forward, continuing. "Surely you, of all women in the White Tower, can see the importance of the Ajahs working together. We need women with different skills and interests to gather into Ajahs. But does it make sense for us to refuse to work together?"

"ðə waɪɾ əz nɑt kɑz ðɪs . . . ɹɪɡɹɛɾəbəl tɛnʃən," mijɑsi sɛd wɪð ə lɪɾəl snɔɹt. "ði ʌðɝz æktɪŋ wɪð sətʃ əbʌndəns ʌv ɪmoʊʃən əv kɹieɪɾəd ɪt."

"The White has not caused this . . . regrettable tension," Miyasi said with a little snort. "The others acting with such abundance of emotion have created it."

"ðə pɹɛzən liɾɝʃɪp əz kɑzd ɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ə liɾɝʃɪp wɪtʃ titʃəz ðəɾ ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt tə stɪl fɛloʊ sɪstɝz ɪn sikɹət, tə ɛksəkjut wɔɹɾɝz bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ ivən bɹɔt tə tʃɹaɪəl. ðət ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð ɹimuvɪŋ ə sɪstɝz ʃɔl ən ɹədusɪŋ əɹ tə ən æksɛptɪd, ðət ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð dɪsbændɪŋ ən ɪntaɪɝ ədʒɑ. ən wʌɾ ʌv æktɪŋ wɪθaʊt ðə kaʊnsəl ə ðə hɔl ɪn sʌmθɪŋ əz deɪnʒɝəs əz kɪdnæpɪŋ ən ɪmpɹɪzənɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ɪz ɪɾ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd ðət ðə sɪstɝz wəd bi soʊ fɹaɪɾənd ən wɝid? ɪz ɪt nɑɾ ɔl kəmplitli lɑdʒɪkəl, wʌɾ əz hæpən tə ʌs?"

"The present leadership has caused it," Egwene said, "a leadership which teaches that it's all right to still fellow sisters in secret, to execute Warders before their Aes Sedai are even brought to trial. That there's nothing wrong with removing a sister's shawl and reducing her to an Accepted, that there's nothing wrong with disbanding an entire Ajah. And what of acting without the counsel of the Hall in something as dangerous as kidnapping and imprisoning the Dragon Reborn? Is it unexpected that the sisters would be so frightened and worried? Is it not all completely logical, what has happened to us?"

ðə θɹi waɪts wɝ kwaɪət.

The three Whites were quiet.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt səbmɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "nɑt waɪl duɪŋ soʊ livz əs fɹæktʃɝd. əl kəntɪnju tə əsɝt ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə ɪz nɑt ði æmɪɝlɪn. hɝ ækʃənz əv pɹuvən ɪt. jə wɑnə hɛlp bæɾəl ðə dɑɹk wʌn? wɛl, jəɹ fɝst stɛp ɪz nɑt tə dil wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. jəɹ fɝst stɛp ʃəd bi tə ɹitʃ aʊt tə sɪstɝz ə ði ʌðɝ ədʒəz."

"I will not submit," Egwene said. "Not while doing so leaves us fractured. I will continue to assert that Elaida is not the Amyrlin. Her actions have proven it. You want to help battle the Dark One? Well, your first step is not to deal with the Dragon Reborn. Your first step should be to reach out to sisters of the other Ajahs."

"waɪ ʌs?" tɛzən sɛd. "ði ækʃənz ʌv ʌðɝz ɑɹ nɑɾ əɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi."

"Why us?" Tesan said. "The actions of others are not our responsibility."

"æn jə ɑɹ nɑt tə bleɪm əɾ ɔl?" ɛɡwin æskt, lɛɾɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ə hɝ æŋɡɝ sip θɹu. wəd nʌn ə hɝ sɪstɝz æksɛpt ə mɑɾɪkəm ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi? "ju, ʌv ðə waɪt, ʃʊɾə sin wɛɹ ðɪs ɹoʊd wəd lɛd. jɛs, sɪuən ən ðə blu wɝ nɑt wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ flɔz - bʌt jə ʃʊɾə sin ðə flɔ ɪn pʊlɪŋ əɹ daʊn, ðən əlaʊɪŋ ɪleɪɾə tə dɪsbæn ðə blu. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ bɪliv ðət sɛvɹəl mɛmbɝz ə jəɹ oʊn ədʒɑ wɝ ɪntəɡɹəl tə ði ækt ə sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ɪleɪɾə əz æmɪɝlɪn."

"And you are not to blame at all?" Egwene asked, letting a little of her anger seep through. Would none of her sisters accept a modicum of responsibility? "You, of the White, should have seen where this road would lead. Yes, Siuan and the Blue were not without their flaws - but you should have seen the flaw in pulling her down, then allowing Elaida to disband the Blue. Besides, I believe that several members of your own Ajah were integral to the act of setting up Elaida as Amyrlin."

mijɑsi ɹikɔɪl slaɪtli. ðə waɪts dɪd nɑt laɪk tə bi ɹimaɪndəɾ ʌv ɑlviɛɝɪn ən əɹ feɪljɝ əz ɪleɪɾəz kipɝ. ɪnstɛɾ ə tɝnɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə fəɹ aʊstɪŋ ðə waɪt, ðeɪ sim tə hæv tɝn əɡɛns ðɛɹ oʊn mɛmbɝ fəɹ ðə ʃeɪm ʃi hæd kɑz ðɛm.

Miyasi recoiled slightly. The Whites did not like to be reminded of Alviarin and her failure as Elaida's Keeper. Instead of turning against Elaida for ousting the White, they seemed to have turned against their own member for the shame she had caused them.

"aɪ stɪl θɪŋk ðət ðɪs ɪz wɝk fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪz," tɛzən sɛd, bʌt ʃi saʊndəd lɛs kənvɪns ðən ʃi hæd dʒʌs moʊməns bɪfɔɹ. "ju ʃəd spik wɪð ðɛm."

"I still think that this is work for the Grays," Tesan said, but she sounded less convinced than she had just moments before. "You should speak with them."

"aɪ hæv," ɛɡwin sɛd. hɝ peɪʃəns wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fɹeɪ. "sʌm wɪl nɑt spik wɪð mi ən kəntɪnju tə sɛn mi tə pɛnəns. ʌðɝz seɪ ðiz ɹɪfs ɑɹ nɑt ðɛɹ fɔlt, bʌt wɪð səm koʊksɪŋ əv əɡɹid tə də wʌt ðeɪ kæn. ðə jɛloʊz əv bɪn vɛɹi ɹizənəbəl, ən aɪ θɪŋk ðəɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə si ðə pɹɑbləmz ɪn ðə taʊɝ əz ə waʊn tə bi hild. ɪm stɪl wɝkɪŋ wɪð sɛvɹəl bɹaʊn sɪstɝz  - ðeɪ sim mɔɹ fæsəneɪɾəd baɪ ðə pɹɑbləmz ðən wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðɛm. aɪv sɛn sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm lʊkɪŋ θɹu ðə hɪstɝiz fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəlz ə dɪvɪʒən, hoʊpɪŋ ðəl ɹʌn əkɹɔs ðə stɔɹi ʌv ɹɪnɑlə mɝlən. ðə kənɛkʃən ʃəd bi izi tə meɪk, ən pɝhæps ðəl bɪɡɪn tə si ðəɾ əɹ pɹɑbləmz hɪɹ kən bi sɑlvd.

"I have," Egwene said. Her patience was beginning to fray. "Some will not speak with me and continue to send me to penance. Others say these rifts are not their fault, but with some coaxing have agreed to do what they can. The Yellows have been very reasonable, and I think they're beginning to see the problems in the Tower as a wound to be healed. I'm still working with several Brown sisters  - they seem more fascinated by the problems than worried about them. I've sent several of them looking through the histories for examples of division, hoping they'll run across the story of Renala Merlon. The connection should be easy to make, and perhaps they will begin to see that our problems here can be solved.

"ðə ɡɹinz hæv, aɪɹɑnɪkli, bɪn ðə moʊst stʌbɝn. ðeɪ kən bi vɛɹi laɪk ɹɛdz ɪn mɛni weɪz, wɪtʃ ɪz ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ əz ðeɪ ɹɪli ʃəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛp mi əz wʌn u wʊɾə bɪn əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðəɾ oʊnli livz ðə blu, hu hæv bɪn bænɪʃt, ən ðə ɹɛd. aɪ daʊt ðət sɪstɝz ə ðət læst ədʒɑ ɑɹ gɑnə bi vɛɹi ɹɪsɛptɪv tə maɪ sədʒɛstʃənz."

"The Greens have, ironically, been the most stubborn. They can be very like Reds in many ways, which is infuriating as they really should be willing to accept me as one who would have been among them. That only leaves the Blue, who have been banished, and the Red. I doubt that sisters of that last Ajah are going to be very receptive to my suggestions."

fɛɹən sæt bæk, θɔtfəl, ən tɛzən sæt wɪð θɹi fɝɡɑɾən wɔlnʌts ɪn əɹ hænd, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin. mijɑsi skɹætʃt əɾ əɹ aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ, aɪz waɪd wɪð sɝpɹaɪz.

Ferane sat back, thoughtful, and Tesan sat with three forgotten walnuts in her hand, staring at Egwene. Miyasi scratched at her iron-gray hair, eyes wide with surprise.

hæɾ ɛɡwin ɡɪvən əweɪ tu mʌtʃ? ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɹɪmɑɹkəbli laɪk ɹænd ælθɹ; ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk tə noʊ wən ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ mənuvɝd.

Had Egwene given away too much? Aes Sedai were remarkably like Rand al'Thor; they did not like to know when they were being maneuvered.

"ju ɑɹ ʃɑkt," ʃi sɛd. "wʌt, dʒju θɪŋk aɪ ʃəd sɪmpli sɪt - laɪk moʊst - ən də nʌθɪŋ waɪl ðə taʊɝ kɹʌmbəlz? ðɪs waɪt dʒɹɛs əz bɪn fɔɹst əpɑn mi, ən aɪ də nɑɾ æksɛpt wʌɾ ɪt ɹɛpɹəzɛns, bʌɾ əl juz ɪt. ə wʊmən ɪn nɑvəs waɪɾ ɪz wʌn ə ðə fju hu kən pæs fɹəm wʌn ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝ tə ənʌðɝ ðiz deɪz. sʌmwʌn əz tə wɝk tə mɛn ðə taʊɝ, ən aɪm ðə bɛs tʃɔɪs.

"You are shocked," she said. "What, do you think I should simply sit - like most - and do nothing while the Tower crumbles? This white dress has been forced upon me, and I do not accept what it represents, but I will use it. A woman in novice white is one of the few who can pass from one Ajah quarter to another these days. Someone has to work to mend the Tower, and I am the best choice.

bɪsaɪdz, ɪts maɪ duɾi."

Besides, it is my duty."

"haʊ vɛɹi . . . ɹizənəbəl ə ju," fɛɹən sɛd, hɝ eɪdʒləs bɹaʊ fɝoʊd.

"How very . . . reasonable of you," Ferane said, her ageless brow furrowed.

"θæŋk ju," ɛɡwin sɛd. wɝ ðeɪ wɝid ðət ʃiɾ oʊvɝstɛpt əɹ baʊnz? æŋɡɝd ðət ʃid bɪn mənɪpjəleɪɾɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ? koʊldli dɪtɝmən tə si hɝ pʌnɪʃt jɛɾ əɡɛn?

"Thank you," Egwene said. Were they worried that she'd overstepped her bounds? Angered that she'd been manipulating Aes Sedai? Coldly determined to see her punished yet again?

fɛɹən lin fɔɹwɝd. "lɛɾ əs seɪ ðət wi wɪʃt tə wɝk təwɔɹd mɛndɪŋ ðə taʊɝ. wʌt pæθ wəd jə ɹɛkəmɛnd?"

Ferane leaned forward. "Let us say that we wished to work toward mending the Tower. What path would you recommend?"

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ʌv ɪksaɪtmənt. ʃid hæd nʌθɪŋ bʌt sɛtbæks dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs fju deɪz. ɪɾiət ɡɹinz! ðeɪ wəd fil fulɪʃ ɪndid wʌns ʃi wɑz æksɛptɪɾ əz æmɪɝlɪn.

Egwene felt a surge of excitement. She'd had nothing but setbacks during the last few days. Idiot Greens! They would feel foolish indeed once she was accepted as Amyrlin.

"swænə, ʌv ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, wɪl sun bi ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ jə θɹi tə ʃɛɹ ə mil wɪð hɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. ət list, swænə wəd meɪk ði ɔfɝ, wʌns ɛɡwin pɹɑɾɪd hɝ. "æksɛpt ən teɪk jəɹ mil ɪn ə pʌblɪk pleɪs, pɝhæps wʌn ə ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾənz. bi sin ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝz kʌmpəni. əl tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ ə bɹaʊn sɪstɝ tə ɪnvaɪt jə nɛkst. lɛt jɝsɛlf bi sin baɪ ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz mɪksɪŋ əmʌŋ ði ədʒəz."

"Suana, of the Yellow Ajah, will soon be inviting you three to share a meal with her," Egwene said. At least, Suana would make the offer, once Egwene prodded her. "Accept and take your meal in a public place, perhaps one of the Tower gardens. Be seen enjoying one another's company. I will try to get a Brown sister to invite you next. Let yourself be seen by the other sisters mixing among the Ajahs."

"sɪmpəl ɪnʌf," mijɑsi sɛd. "vɛɹi lɪɾəl ɛfɝt ɹikwaɪɝd, bʌɾ ɛksələn pətɛnʃəl fəɹ ɡeɪn."

"Simple enough," Miyasi said. "Very little effort required, but excellent potential for gain."

"wi ʃæl si," fɛɹən sɛd. "ju meɪ wɪðdʒɹɔ, ɛɡwin."

"We shall see," Ferane said. "You may withdraw, Egwene."

ʃi dɪdn laɪk biɪŋ dɪsmɪst soʊ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɛlpɪŋ ɪt. stɪl, ðə wʊmən hæd ʃoʊn ɛɡwin ɹɪspɛk baɪ juzɪŋ əɹ neɪm. ɛɡwin stʊɾ ʌp, ən ðən - vɛɹi kɛɹfəli - nɑɾəd əɹ hɛd tə fɛɹən. ðoʊ tɛzən ən mijɑsi ɡeɪv noʊ stʃɹɔŋ ɹiækʃənz, boʊθ pɛɹz ʌv aɪz waɪɾənd slaɪtli. baɪ naʊ, ɪt wɑz wɛl noʊn ɪn ðə taʊɝ ðəɾ ɛɡwin nɛvɝ kɝtsid. ænd, ʃɑkɪŋli, fɛɹən baʊɾ əɹ hɛd, dʒʌst ə dɪɡɹi, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðə dʒɛstʃɝ.

She didn't like being dismissed so, but there was no helping it. Still, the woman had shown Egwene respect by using her name. Egwene stood up, and then - very carefully - nodded her head to Ferane. Though Tesan and Miyasi gave no strong reactions, both pairs of eyes widened slightly. By now, it was well known in the Tower that Egwene never curtsied. And, shockingly, Ferane bowed her head, just a degree, returning the gesture.

"ʃʊd jə dɪsaɪd tə tʃuz ðə waɪt, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," ðə wʊmən sɛd, "noʊ ðət jəl faɪn ə wɛlkəm hɪɹ. jəɹ lɑdʒɪk ðɪs deɪ wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl fəɹ wʌn soʊ jʌŋ."

"Should you decide to choose the White, Egwene al'Vere," the woman said, "know that you will find a welcome here. Your logic this day was remarkable for one so young."

ɛɡwin hɪɾ ə smaɪl. dʒʌs fɔɹ deɪz bæk, bɛn nælsəd hæɾ ɔl bʌɾ ɔfɝɾ ɛɡwin ə pleɪs ɪn ðə bɹaʊn, ən ɛɡwin wɑz stɪl sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ vɪdʒələnli swænə ɹɛkəmɛndəd ðə jɛloʊ tə hɝ.

Egwene hid a smile. Just four days back, Bennae Nalsad had all but offered Egwene a place in the Brown, and Egwene was still surprised at how vigilantly Suana recommended the Yellow to her.

ɔlmoʊs ðeɪ meɪɾ əɹ tʃeɪnʒ əɹ maɪnd - bʌt ðət wɑz moʊsli hɝ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən wɪð ðə ɡɹin ət ðə moʊmənt. "θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛd. "bʌt jə mʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn mʌst ɹɛpɹəzɛn ɔl ədʒəz.

Almost they made her change her mind - but that was mostly her frustration with the Green at the moment. "Thank you," she said. "But you must remember that the Amyrlin must represent all Ajahs.

əɹ dɪskʌʃən wɑz ɛndʒɔɪəbəl, haʊɛvɝ. aɪ hoʊp ðət jəl əlaʊ mi tə dʒɔɪn jə əɡɛn ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ."

Our discussion was enjoyable, however. I hope that you will allow me to join you again in the future."

wɪð ðæt, ɛɡwin wɪθdʒɹu, lɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf smaɪl bɹɔdli əz ʃi nɑɾəd tə fɛɹənz stɝɾi, boʊlɪɡd wɔɹɾɝ stændɪŋ ɡɑɹd dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə bælkəni. hɝ smaɪl læstəd ɹaɪɾ ʌp əntɪl ʃi lɛf ðə waɪt sɛktɝ ə ðə taʊɝ ən faʊn keɪɾɝin weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. ðə ɹɛd wɑz nɑt wʌn ə ðə tu əsaɪn tə ɛɡwin ɝliɝ ɪn ðə deɪ, ən tɔk əbaʊt ðə taʊɝ sɛd ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑz ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn keɪɾɝin mɔɹ ən mɔɹ naʊ ðəɾ əɹ kipɝ hæd vænɪʃt ɑn ə mɪstɪɹiəs mɪʃən.

With that, Egwene withdrew, letting herself smile broadly as she nodded to Ferane's sturdy, bowlegged Warder standing guard just inside the balcony. Her smile lasted right up until she left the White sector of the Tower and found Katerine waiting in the hallway. The Red was not one of the two assigned to Egwene earlier in the day, and talk about the Tower said that Elaida was relying on Katerine more and more now that her Keeper had vanished on a mysterious mission.

keɪɾɝinz ʃɑɹp feɪs bɔɹ ə smaɪl ʌv ɪts oʊn. ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡʊd saɪn. "hɪɹ," ðə wʊmən sɛd, ɔfɝɪŋ ə wʊɾən kʌp hoʊldɪŋ ə klɪɹ lɪkwəd. ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ɛɡwinz æftɝnun doʊs ə fɔkɹut.

Katerine's sharp face bore a smile of its own. That was not a good sign. "Here," the woman said, offering a wooden cup holding a clear liquid. It was time for Egwene's afternoon dose of forkroot.

ɛɡwin ɡɹɪməst, bʌt tʊk ðə kʌp ən dʒɹæŋk ðə kɑntɛns. ʃi waɪpt əɹ maʊθ wɪð əɹ hæŋkɝtʃɪf, ðən bɪɡæn tə wɔk daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ.

Egwene grimaced, but took the cup and drank the contents. She wiped her mouth with her handkerchief, then began to walk down the hallway.

"ænd wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?" keɪɾɝin æskt.

"And where are you going?" Katerine asked.

ðə smʌɡnəs ɪn əɹ toʊn meɪɾ ɛɡwin hɛzəteɪt. ɛɡwin tɝnd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "maɪ nɛks lɛsən - "

The smugness in her tone made Egwene hesitate. Egwene turned, frowning. "My next lesson - "

"ju wɪl əv noʊ fɝðɝ lɛsənz," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "æt list, nɑɾ ə ðə kaɪn juv bɪn ɹəsivɪŋ. ɔl əɡɹi ðət jəɹ skɪl wɪð wivz ɪz ɪmpɹɛsɪv, fəɹ ə nɑvəs."

"You will have no further lessons," Katerine said. "At least, not of the kind you have been receiving. All agree that your skill with weaves is impressive, for a novice."

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd. wɝ ðeɪ gɑnə ɹeɪz əɹ tə æksɛptɪɾ əɡɛn? ʃi daʊɾɪd ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wəɾ əlaʊ hɝ ɛni mɔɹ fɹiɾəm, ən ʃi ɹɛɹli spɛn ɛni taɪm ɪn əɹ kɔɹɾɝz, soʊ ði ɛkstʃɹə speɪs wəd bi ənɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Egwene frowned. Were they going to raise her to Accepted again? She doubted that Elaida would allow her any more freedom, and she rarely spent any time in her quarters, so the extra space would be unimportant.

"noʊ," keɪɾɝin sɛd, tɔɪɪŋ aɪdli wɪð ðə fɹɪnʒ ɑn əɹ ʃɔl. "wʌt jə nid tə lɝn, ɪts bɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd, ɪz hjumɪlɪɾi. ði æmɪɝlɪn əz hɝɾ ə jəɹ fulɪʃ ɹəfjuzəl tə kɝtsi tə sɪstɝz. ɪn əɹ əpɪnjən, ɪts ðə læst sɪmbəl ə jəɹ dɪfaɪənt neɪtʃɝ, ən soʊ jə ɑɹ tə ɹəsiv ə nu fɔɹm ʌv ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən."

"No," Katerine said, toying idly with the fringe on her shawl. "What you need to learn, it has been decided, is humility. The Amyrlin has heard of your foolish refusal to curtsy to sisters. In her opinion, it's the last symbol of your defiant nature, and so you are to receive a new form of instruction."

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə moʊmən ə fɪɹ. "wʌt kaɪndə ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən?" ʃi sɛd, kipɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs ivən.

Egwene felt a moment of fear. "What kind of instruction?" she said, keeping her voice even.

"tʃɔɹz ən wɝk," keɪɾɝin sɛd.

"Chores and work," Katerine said.

"aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi də tʃɔɹz, dʒʌs laɪk ðə nɑvəsɪz."

"I already do chores, just like the novices."

"ju mɪsteɪk mi," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "fɹʌm naʊ ɑn, ɔl jəl də ɪz tʃɔɹz. jə ɑɹ tə ɹipɔɹt tə ðə kɪtʃənz ɪmiɾiətli - jəl spɛn ɛvɹi æftɝnun wɝkɪŋ ðɛɹ. ɪn ði ivnɪŋz, jəl skɹʌb flɔɹz. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋz jəl ɹipɔɹt tə ðə ɡɹaʊnzmæstɝ ən wɝk ðə ɡɑɹɾənz. ðɪs wɪl bi jəɹ laɪf, ðoʊz seɪm θɹi æktɪvəɾiz ɛvɹi deɪ - faɪv aʊɝz əɾ itʃ wʌn - əntɪl jə ɡɪv ʌp jəɹ fulɪʃ pɹaɪɾ ən lɝn tə kɝtsi tə jəɹ bɛɾɝz."

"You mistake me," Katerine said. "From now on, all you will do is chores. You are to report to the kitchens immediately - you will spend every afternoon working there. In the evenings, you will scrub floors. In the mornings you will report to the groundsmaster and work the gardens. This will be your life, those same three activities every day - five hours at each one - until you give up your foolish pride and learn to curtsy to your betters."

ɪt wɑz ən ɛn tə ɛɡwinz fɹiɾəm, wʌt lɪɾəl ʃi hæd. ðəɹ wɑz ɡli ɪn keɪɾɝinz aɪz.

It was an end to Egwene's freedom, what little she had. There was glee in Katerine's eyes.

"ɑ, soʊ jə ʌndɝstænd," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "noʊ mɔɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ sɪstɝz ɪn ðɛɹ kɔɹɾɝz, weɪstɪŋ ðɛɹ taɪm əz jə pɹæktəs wivz ðət juv ɔlɹɛɾi mæstɝd. noʊ mɔɹ leɪzinəs; naʊ jəl wɝk ɪnstɛd. wʌt θɪŋk jə ʌv ðæt?"

"Ah, so you understand," Katerine said. "No more visiting sisters in their quarters, wasting their time as you practice weaves that you have already mastered. No more laziness; now you will work instead. What think you of that?"

ɪt wɑzn ðə dɪfəkəlti ʌv ðə wɝk ðət wɝiɾ ɛɡwin - ʃi dɪdn maɪn ðə tʃɔɹz ʃi dɪɾ itʃ deɪ. ɪt wɑz ðə læk ə kɑntækt wɪð ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ðət wəd ɹuən hɝ. haʊ wəd ʃi mɛn ðə waɪt taʊɝ? laɪt! ɪt wɑz ə dɪzæstɝ.

It wasn't the difficulty of the work that worried Egwene - she didn't mind the chores she did each day. It was the lack of contact with other sisters that would ruin her. How would she mend the White Tower? Light! It was a disaster.

ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ ən fɔɹs daʊn əɹ ɪmoʊʃən. ʃi mɛt keɪɾɝinz aɪz, seɪɪŋ, "vɛɹi wɛl.

She gritted her teeth and forced down her emotion. She met Katerine's eyes, saying, "Very well.

lɛɾ əs ɡoʊ."

Let us go."

keɪɾɝin blɪŋkt. ʃiɾ ɑbviəsli ɪkspɛktəɾ ə tæntʃɹəm, əɹ ət list ə faɪt. bʌt ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə taɪm.

Katerine blinked. She'd obviously expected a tantrum, or at least a fight. But this was not the time.

ɛɡwin tɝn əɹ stɛp təwɔɹd ðə kɪtʃənz, livɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝz ə ðə waɪts bɪhaɪnd. ʃi kʊdn lɛɾ əm noʊ haʊ ɪfɛktɪv ðɪs pʌnɪʃmənt wɑz.

Egwene turned her step toward the kitchens, leaving the quarters of the Whites behind. She couldn't let them know how effective this punishment was.

ʃi fɔɹs daʊn əɹ pænɪk əz ʃi wɔkt, ðə kævɝnəs hɔlweɪz ə ði ɪnɝ taʊɝ laɪnd wɪð bɹækəɾɪd læmps, lɔŋ ən sɪnwəs, laɪk ðə hɛdz ə sɝpəns spaʊɾɪŋ taɪni fleɪmz ʌp təwɔɹd ðə stoʊn silɪŋ. ʃi kəd dil wɪð ðɪs. ʃi wəd dil wɪð ðɪs. ðeɪ wəd nɑt bɹeɪk hɝ.

She forced down her panic as she walked, the cavernous hallways of the inner Tower lined with bracketed lamps, long and sinuous, like the heads of serpents spouting tiny flames up toward the stone ceiling. She could deal with this. She would deal with this. They would not break her.

pɝhæps ʃi ʃəd wɝk fəɹ ə fju deɪz, ðən pɹitɛn ðət ʃi hæd bɪn hʌmbəld. ʃəd ʃi ɡɪv ðə kɝtsi ɪleɪɾə dɪmændəd? ɪt wɑz ə sɪmpəl θɪŋ, ɹɪli. wʌn kɝtsi, ən ʃi kəd ɡoʊ bæk tə hɝ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt duɾiz.

Perhaps she should work for a few days, then pretend that she had been humbled. Should she give the curtsy Elaida demanded? It was a simple thing, really. One curtsy, and she could go back to her more important duties.

noʊ, ʃi θɔt. noʊ, ðət wəd nɑt bi ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. aɪd luz ðə moʊmən aɪ ɡeɪv ðət fɝs kɝtsi.

No, she thought. No, that would not be the end of it. I'd lose the moment I gave that first curtsy.

ɡɪvɪŋ ɪn wəd pɹuv tə ɪleɪɾə ðəɾ ɛɡwin kəd bi bɹoʊkən. kɝtsiɪŋ wəd bɪɡɪn ə dɪsɛn ɪndə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. sun, ɪleɪɾə wəd dɪsaɪd ðəɾ ɛɡwin niɾəd tə stɑɹt juzɪŋ ɑnɹəfɪks fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn wəd sɛn ɛɡwin bæk tə wɝk dɪteɪl, noʊɪŋ ɪt hæd bɪn ɪfɛktɪv bɪfɔɹ. wəɾ ɛɡwin bɛn ðəɹ tu? haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɛni kɹɛɾəbɪlɪti ʃi hæɾ ɛndəɾ ʌp fɝɡɑɾən, tʃɹæmpəld ɪndə ðə taɪlz ə ðə taʊɝ hɔlweɪz?

Giving in would prove to Elaida that Egwene could be broken. Curtsying would begin a descent into destruction. Soon, Elaida would decide that Egwene needed to start using honorifics for the Aes Sedai. The false Amyrlin would send Egwene back to work detail, knowing it had been effective before. Would Egwene bend there too? How long before any credibility she had ended up forgotten, trampled into the tiles of the Tower hallways?

ʃi kəd nɑt bɛnd. ðə biɾɪŋz hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd əɹ bɪheɪvjɝ; wɝk dɪteɪl mʌs nɑt tʃeɪnʒ əɹ iðɝ.

She could not bend. The beatings had not changed her behavior; work detail must not change her either.

θɹi aʊɝz ʌv wɝkɪŋ ðə kɪtʃənz dɪd lɪɾəl tə ɪmpɹuv əɹ mud. lɑɹəz, ðə hɛfti mɪstʃɹəs ə kɪtʃənz, hæd sɛɾ ɛɡwin ət skɹʌbɪŋ aʊt wʌn ə ði ʌvɛnlaɪk faɪɝpleɪsəz. ɪt wɑz dɝɾi, ɡɹaɪmi wɝk, nɑt kəndusɪv tə θɪŋkɪŋ. nɑt ðət ðəɹ wɝ mɛni weɪz aʊɾ ə hɝ sɪtʃueɪʃən.

Three hours of working the kitchens did little to improve her mood. Laras, the hefty Mistress of Kitchens, had set Egwene at scrubbing out one of the ovenlike fireplaces. It was dirty, grimy work, not conducive to thinking. Not that there were many ways out of her situation.

ɛɡwin nɛl bæk ɑn əɹ hilz, ɹeɪzɪŋ ən ɑɹm ən waɪpɪŋ əɹ bɹaʊ. ði ɑɹm keɪm əweɪ smɪɹd wɪð sʊt. ɛɡwin saɪd sɔfli, hɝ maʊθ ən noʊz pɹətɛktəd baɪ ə dæmp klɔθ tə kip əɹ fɹəm bɹiðɪŋ tu mʌtʃ æʃ. hɝ bɹɛθ wɑz hɑɾ ən stʌfi əɡɛnst əɹ feɪs, ən əɹ skɪn wɑz stɪki wɪð swɛt. ðə dʒɹɑps ðət fɛl fɹəm əɹ feɪs wɝ steɪnd wɪð blæk sʊt; θɹu ðə klɔθ ʃi kəd smɛl ðə dʌl, kɹʌsti sɛn ʌv æʃ ðət hæd bɪn bɝn oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ əɡɛn.

Egwene knelt back on her heels, raising an arm and wiping her brow. The arm came away smeared with soot. Egwene sighed softly, her mouth and nose protected by a damp cloth to keep her from breathing too much ash. Her breath was hot and stuffy against her face, and her skin was sticky with sweat. The drops that fell from her face were stained with black soot; through the cloth she could smell the dull, crusty scent of ash that had been burned over and over and over again.

ðə faɪɝpleɪs wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ skwɛɹ kənstʃɹʌkʃən ə bɝn ɹɛd bɹɪks. ɪt wɑz oʊpən ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ən mɔɹ ðən lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə kɹɔl ɪndə - wɪtʃ wɑz ɪɡzækli wʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd tə du. dɑɹk kɹʌsts bɪlt ʌp ɑn ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə flu ən tʃɪmni, ən ðeɪ niɾəd tə bi skɹʌb fɹi lɛs ðeɪ klɑɡ ðə tʃɪmni əɹ bɹeɪk fɹi ən fɔl ɪndə ðə fud. aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə daɪnɪŋ ɹum, ɛɡwin kəd hɪɹ keɪɾɝin ən lɹin tʃæɾɪŋ ən læfɪŋ wɪð itʃ ʌðɝ. ðə ɹɛdz piɹiɑɾɪkəli poʊk hɛdz ɪn tə tʃɛk ɑn hɝ, bʌɾ əɹ ɹil supɝvaɪzɝ wɑz lɑɹəz, hu wɑz skɹʌbɪŋ pɑts ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum.

The fireplace was a large square construction of burned red bricks. It was open on both sides and more than large enough to crawl into - which was exactly what Egwene had to do. Dark crusts built up on the inside of the flue and chimney, and they needed to be scrubbed free lest they clog the chimney or break free and fall into the food. Outside in the dining room, Egwene could hear Katerine and Lirene chatting and laughing with each other. The Reds periodically poked heads in to check on her, but her real supervisor was Laras, who was scrubbing pots on the other side of the room.

ɛɡwin hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪndə ə wɝk dʒɹɛs fəɹ ðə duɾi. waɪl ɪt hæd wʌns bɪn waɪt, ɪt hæd bɪn ɹɪpiɾɪdli juz baɪ nɑvəsɪz klinɪŋ ðə faɪɝpleɪsəz, ən ðə sʊt hæd bɪn ɡɹaʊn ɪndə ðə faɪbɝz.

Egwene had changed into a work dress for the duty. While it had once been white, it had been repeatedly used by novices cleaning the fireplaces, and the soot had been ground into the fibers.

pætʃəz ʌv ɡɹeɪ steɪn ðə klɔθ, laɪk ʃædoʊz.

Patches of gray stained the cloth, like shadows.

ʃi ɹʌb ðə smɔl ə hɝ bæk, ɡɑt bæk ɑn əɹ hænz ən niz, ən kɹɔl fɑɹðɝ ɪndə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. juzɪŋ ə smɔl wʊɾən skɹeɪp, ʃi wɝkt klʌmps ʌv æʃ fɹi fɹəm simz bɪtwin ðə bɹɪks, ðən ɡæðɝɾ ɪɾ ʌp ən dəpɑzɪɾɪd ɪɾ ɪn bɹæs bʌkəts, ðə ɹɪmz ʌv wɪtʃ wɝ paʊɾɝd waɪɾ ən ɡɹeɪ wɪð æʃ. hɝ fɝs tæsk hæd bɪn tə dɪɡ aʊɾ ɔl ə ðə lus sʊɾ ən paɪl ɪɾ ɪndə ðə bʌkəts.

She rubbed the small of her back, got back on her hands and knees, and crawled farther into the fireplace. Using a small wooden scrape, she worked clumps of ash free from seams between the bricks, then gathered it up and deposited it in brass buckets, the rims of which were powdered white and gray with ash. Her first task had been to dig out all of the loose soot and pile it into the buckets.

hɝ hænz wɝ soʊ blækən fɹəm ðə wɝk ʃi wɝid ðət ðə moʊs fjʊɹiəs skɹʌbɪŋ wʊdnt ɡɛɾ əm klin. hɝ niz ætʃt, ən ðeɪ simd ə stʃɹeɪnʒ kaʊntɝpɑɹt tə hɝ bæksaɪd, wɪtʃ stɪl stʌŋ fɹəm əɹ ɹɛɡjəlɝ mɔɹnɪŋ biɾɪŋ.

Her hands were so blackened from the work she worried that the most furious scrubbing wouldn't get them clean. Her knees ached, and they seemed a strange counterpart to her backside, which still stung from her regular morning beating.

ʃi kəntɪnjud, skɹætʃɪŋ wɪð əɹ skɹeɪp əɾ ə blækən sɛkʃən ə bɹɪk, dɪmli lɪt baɪ ðə læntɝn ʃid lɛf bɝnɪŋ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ɪnsaɪd ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ʃi ɪtʃt tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ; bʌt ðə ɹɛdz aʊtsaɪd wəd sɛns əɹ tʃænəlɪŋ, ən ʃid dɪskʌvɝd ðəɾ əɹ æftɝnun doʊs ə fɔkɹut hæd bɪn ʌnkɛɹɪktɝɪstɪkli stʃɹɔŋ, livɪŋ əɹ əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl əz mʌtʃ əz ə tʃɹɪkəl. ɪn fækt, ɪt hæd bɪn stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə liv əɹ dʒɹaʊzi, wɪtʃ meɪd ðə wɝk ivən hɑɹɾɝ.

She continued, scratching with her scrape at a blackened section of brick, dimly lit by the lantern she'd left burning in a corner inside the fireplace. She itched to use the One Power; but the Reds outside would sense her channeling, and she'd discovered that her afternoon dose of forkroot had been uncharacteristically strong, leaving her unable to channel as much as a trickle. In fact, it had been strong enough to leave her drowsy, which made the work even harder.

wɑz ðɪs tə bi hɝ laɪf? tʃɹæpt ɪnsaɪɾ ə faɪɝpleɪs, skɹʌbɪŋ ət bɹɪks noʊbɑdi sɔ, lɑkt əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɝld? ʃi kʊdn stæn ʌp tə ɪleɪɾə ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn fɝɡɑɾ əbaʊt hɝ. ʃi kɔf kwaɪətli, ðə saʊn ɛkoʊɪŋ əɡɛns ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs.

Was this to be her life? Trapped inside a fireplace, scrubbing at bricks nobody saw, locked away from the world? She couldn't stand up to Elaida if everyone forgot about her. She coughed quietly, the sound echoing against the inside of the fireplace.

ʃi niɾəd ə plæn. hɝ oʊnli ɹikɔɹs sim tə bi tə juz ðə sɪstɝz u wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹuɾ aʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ. bʌt haʊ tə vɪzət ðɛm? wɪθaʊt biɪŋ tʃɹeɪn baɪ sɪstɝz, ʃi hæd noʊ weɪ tə ɪskeɪp əɹ ɹɛd hænlɝz baɪ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə doʊmeɪnz ʌv ʌðɝ ədʒəz. kəd ʃi snik əweɪ sʌmhaʊ waɪl duɪŋ leɪbɝ? ɪf əɹ æbsəns wɝ dɪskʌvɝd, ʃid pɹɑbli ɛn ʌp ɪn ən ivən wɝs sɪtʃueɪʃən.

She needed a plan. Her only recourse seemed to be to use the sisters who were trying to root out the Black Ajah. But how to visit them? Without being trained by sisters, she had no way to escape her Red handlers by entering the domains of other Ajahs. Could she sneak away somehow while doing labor? If her absence were discovered, she'd probably end up in an even worse situation.

bʌt ʃi kʊdn lɛɾ əɹ laɪf bi dɑməneɪɾəd baɪ ðɪs miniəl leɪbɝ! ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɹæn fɹi, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz ɑn əɹ hænz ən niz klinɪŋ faɪɝpleɪsəz!

But she couldn't let her life be dominated by this menial labor! The Last Battle was approaching, the Dragon Reborn ran free, and the Amyrlin Seat was on her hands and knees cleaning fireplaces!

ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ, skɹʌbɪŋ fjʊɹiəsli. ðə sʊt hæd bɪn beɪkt ɑn fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ ðəɾ ɪt fɔɹmd ə ɡlɔsi blæk pətinə ɑn ðə stoʊn. ʃid nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɪɾ ɔl ɔf. ʃi dʒʌs niɾəd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz klin ɪnʌf ðət nʌn wəd bɹeɪk fɹi.

She gritted her teeth, scrubbing furiously. The soot had been baked on for so long that it formed a glossy black patina on the stone. She'd never get it all off. She just needed to make sure it was clean enough that none would break free.
