ɹəflɛktəɾ ɪn ðət ɡlɔsi pətinə, ʃi sɔ ə ʃædoʊ muv əkɹɔs ði oʊpənɪŋ ə ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ɛɡwin ɪmiɾiətli ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə sɔɹs - bʌt, ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi faʊnd nʌθɪŋ. nɑt wɪð fɔkɹut klaʊɾɪŋ əɹ maɪnd. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz dɛfənətli sʌmwʌn aʊtsaɪd ðə faɪɝpleɪs, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ daʊn, muvɪŋ kwaɪətli. . . .

Reflected in that glossy patina, she saw a shadow move across the opening of the far side of the fireplace. Egwene immediately reached for the Source - but, of course, she found nothing. Not with forkroot clouding her mind. But there was definitely someone outside the fireplace, crouching down, moving quietly. . . .

ɛɡwin ɡɹɪp ðə skɹeɪp ɪn wʌn hænd, sloʊli ɹitʃɪŋ daʊn wɪð ði ʌðɝ tə ɡɹæb ðə bɹʌʃ ʃid bɪn juzɪŋ tə skup ʌp æʃ. ðən ʃi spʌn.

Egwene gripped the scrape in one hand, slowly reaching down with the other to grab the brush she'd been using to scoop up ash. Then she spun.

lɑɹəz fɹoʊz, pikɪŋ ɪndə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə kɪtʃənz wɔɹ ə lɑɹdʒ waɪɾ eɪpɹən, steɪnd wɪð ə fju sʊt mɑɹks ɪtsɛlf. hɝ pʌdʒi ɹaʊn feɪs hæd sin ɪts ʃɛɹ ʌv wɪntɝz; hɝ hɛɹ wɑz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə ɡɹeɪ, ən laɪnz kɹis ðə saɪdz ə hɝ aɪz. linɪŋ oʊvɝ əz ʃi wɑz, hɝ dʒaʊlz fɔɹmd ə sɛkənd, θɝɾ ən fɔɹθ tʃɪn, ən ʃi ɡɹɪp ðə saɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs oʊpənɪŋ wɪð ə θɪk-fɪŋɡɝd hænd.

Laras froze, peeking into the fireplace. The Mistress of Kitchens wore a large white apron, stained with a few soot marks itself. Her pudgy round face had seen its share of winters; her hair was starting to gray, and lines creased the sides of her eyes. Leaning over as she was, her jowls formed a second, third and fourth chin, and she gripped the side of the fireplace opening with a thick-fingered hand.

ɛɡwin ɹɪlækst. waɪ hæd ʃi bɪn soʊ sɝɾən ðət sʌmwʌn hæd bɪn snikɪŋ ʌp ɑn hɝ? ɪt wɑz dʒʌs lɑɹəz kʌmɪŋ tə tʃɛk ɑn hɝ.

Egwene relaxed. Why had she been so certain that someone had been sneaking up on her? It was just Laras coming to check on her.

jɛt waɪ hæd ðə wʊmən muv soʊ saɪlənli? lɑɹəz ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd, aɪz nɛɹoʊɪŋ. ðən ʃi ɹeɪzd ə fɪŋɡɝ tə hɝ lɪps. ɛɡwin fɛl hɝsɛlf tɛns əɡɛn. wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?

Yet why had the woman moved so silently? Laras glanced to the side, eyes narrowing. Then she raised a finger to her lips. Egwene felt herself tense again. What was going on?

lɑɹəz bækt aʊɾ ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, weɪvɪŋ fəɹ ɛɡwin tə fɑloʊ. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə kɪtʃənz muvd ɑn laɪt fit, fɑɹ kwaɪəɾɝ ðən ɛɡwin wʊɾə θɔt pɑsəbəl. əsɪstən kʊks ən skʌljənz klæŋd əweɪ ɪn ʌðɝ pɑɹts ə ðə kɪtʃən, bʌt nʌn wɝ dɝɛkli vɪzəbəl. ɛɡwin kɹɛp fɹi ʌv ðə faɪɝpleɪs, tʌkɪŋ ðə skɹeɪp ɪndə hɝ bɛlt ən waɪpɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs. ʃi pʊl ðə klɔθ fɹi fɹəm əɹ feɪs, bɹiðɪŋ swit, sʊt-fɹi ɛɹ. ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ən ɹəsivd ə hɑɹʃ ɡlɛɹ fɹəm lɑɹəz, fɑloʊd baɪ ənʌðɝ fɪŋɡɝ tə ðə lɪps.

Laras backed out of the fireplace, waving for Egwene to follow. The Mistress of Kitchens moved on light feet, far quieter than Egwene would have thought possible. Assistant cooks and scullions clanged away in other parts of the kitchen, but none were directly visible. Egwene crept free of the fireplace, tucking the scrape into her belt and wiping her hands on her dress. She pulled the cloth free from her face, breathing sweet, soot-free air. She took a deep breath, and received a harsh glare from Laras, followed by another finger to the lips.

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd, fɑloʊɪŋ lɑɹəz θɹu ðə kɪtʃənz. ɪn ə fju moʊməns ʃi ən ɛɡwin stʊɾ ɪn ə pæntʃɹi, θɪk wɪð ðə sɛn ə dʒɹaɪd ɡɹeɪnz ən eɪdʒɪŋ tʃizɪz. ðə taɪlz ɡeɪv weɪ tə mɔɹ dʊɹəbəl bɹɪkwɝk hɪɹ. lɑɹəz ʃʌvd əsaɪɾ ə fju sæks, ðən pʊld oʊpən ə pis ə ðə flɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ə wʊɾən tʃɹæpdɔɹ, kæpt wɪð ʃeɪv bɹɪkwɝk ɑn ðə tɑp tə meɪk ɪt sim pɑɹɾ ə ðə flɔɹ. ɪt ɹɪvild ə smɔl, ɹɑk-wɔl tʃeɪmbɝ ʌndɝniθ ðə pæntʃɹi, lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ə pɝsən, ðoʊ ə tɔl mæn wəd bi kɹæmpt.

Egwene nodded, following Laras through the kitchens. In a few moments she and Egwene stood in a pantry, thick with the scent of dried grains and aging cheeses. The tiles gave way to more durable brickwork here. Laras shoved aside a few sacks, then pulled open a piece of the floor. It was a wooden trapdoor, capped with shaved brickwork on the top to make it seem part of the floor. It revealed a small, rock-walled chamber underneath the pantry, large enough to hold a person, though a tall man would be cramped.

"ju weɪt hɪɹ əntɪl naɪt," lɑɹəz sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. "aɪ kænt ɡɛt jə aʊt ɹaɪt naʊ, nɑt wɪð ðə taʊɝ flʌɾɝi əz ə jɑɹd fʊl ə hɛnz wən ðə fɑks ɪz əbaʊt. bʌt ðə ɡɑɹbɪdʒ ɡoʊz aʊt leɪɾ ət naɪt, ən əl haɪd jə əmʌŋ ðə ɡɝlz u ənloʊɾ ɪt. ə dɑkwɝkɝ wɪl teɪk jə tə ə smɔl boʊɾ ən ɹoʊ jə əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. aɪ hæv səm fɹɛnz əmʌŋ ðə ɡɑɹd; ðəl tɝn ði ʌðɝ weɪ. wʌns jə ɹitʃ ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ɪts ʌp tə jə wʌt jə du. aɪɾ ædvaɪz əɡɛnst ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə ðoʊz fulz u meɪd jə ðɛɹ pʌpət. faɪn səm pleɪs tə laɪ loʊ əntɪl ðɪs ɔl bloʊz oʊvɝ, ðən kʌm bæk ən si ɪf huɛvɝz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ wɪl teɪk jə ɪn. ɪzən laɪkli ɪɾəl bi ɪleɪɾə, ðə weɪ θɪŋz ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ. . . ."

"You wait here until night," Laras said in a low voice. "I can't get you out right now, not with the Tower fluttery as a yard full of hens when the fox is about. But the garbage goes out late at night, and I'll hide you among the girls who unload it. A dockworker will take you to a small boat and row you across the river. I have some friends among the guard; they'll turn the other way. Once you reach the other side, it's up to you what you do. I'd advise against going back to those fools who made you their puppet. Find some place to lie low until this all blows over, then come back and see if whoever's in charge will take you in. Isn't likely it will be Elaida, the way things are going. . . ."

ɛɡwin blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz.

Egwene blinked in surprise.

"wɛl," ðə hɛvisɛt wʊmən sɛd. "ɪn jə ɡoʊ."

"Well," the heavyset woman said. "In you go."

"aɪ - "

"I - "

"noʊ taɪm fəɹ dʒæbɝɪŋ!" lɑɹəz sɛd, əz ɪf ʃi wɝn ðə wʌn duɪŋ ɔl ə ðə tɔkɪŋ. ʃi wɑz ɑbviəsli nɝvəs, ðə weɪ ʃi kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ əbaʊɾ ən tæpɪŋ əɹ fʊt. bʌt ʃiɾ ɑbviəsli ɔlsoʊ dʌn ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ bɪfɔɹ. waɪ wɑz ðə sɪmpəl kʊk ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ soʊ skɪld ət snikɪŋ, soʊ hændi wɪð ə plæn tə ɡɛɾ ɛɡwin aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹɾəfaɪd ən bɪsidʒ sɪɾi? ən waɪ dɪd ʃi hæv ə boʊlt- hoʊl ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs? laɪt! haʊ hæd ʃi kɹieɪɾəd ɪt?

"No time for jabbering!" Laras said, as if she weren't the one doing all of the talking. She was obviously nervous, the way she kept glancing about and tapping her foot. But she'd obviously also done this sort of thing before. Why was the simple cook in the White Tower so skilled at sneaking, so handy with a plan to get Egwene out of the fortified and besieged city? And why did she have a bolt- hole in the kitchens in the first place? Light! How had she created it?

"doʊnt wɝi əbaʊt mi," lɑɹəz sɛd, aɪɪŋ ɛɡwin. "aɪ kən hændəl maɪsɛlf. əl kip ɔl ə ðə kɪtʃən sɝvəns əweɪ fɹəm wɛɹ jə wɝ wɝkɪŋ. ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ oʊnli tʃɛk ɑn jə ɛvɹi hæf- aʊɝ əɹ soʊ - ən sɪns ðeɪ dʒʌs tʃɛkt ə mɪnəɾ əɡoʊ, ɪɾəl bi ə waɪl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ lʊk ɪn əɡɛn.

"Don't worry about me," Laras said, eyeing Egwene. "I can handle myself. I'll keep all of the kitchen servants away from where you were working. Those Aes Sedai only check on you every half- hour or so - and since they just checked a minute ago, it will be a while before they look in again.

wən ðeɪ də tʃɛk, aɪ kən pliɾ ɪɡnɝəns ən ɛvɹiwʌn wɪl əsum jə slɪpt aʊɾ ə ðə kɪtʃənz.

When they do check, I can plead ignorance and everyone will assume you slipped out of the kitchens.

wɪl sun əv jə aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ən noʊbɑdi wɪl bi ðə waɪzɝ."

We'll soon have you out of the city and nobody will be the wiser."

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd, faɪnəli faɪndɪŋ əɹ tʌŋ, "bʌt waɪ?" ʃi hæɾ əsum ðæt, æftɝ hɛlpɪŋ mɪn ən sɪuən, lɑɹəz wʊdn bi iɡɝ tə hɛlp ənʌðɝ fjudʒəɾɪv.

"Yes," Egwene said, finally finding her tongue, "but why?" She had assumed that, after helping Min and Siuan, Laras wouldn't be eager to help another fugitive.

lɑɹəz lʊk bæk ət hɝ, ɪn ðə wʊmənz aɪz ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən əz hɑɹɾ əz ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪz.

Laras looked back at her, in the woman's eyes a determination as hard as any Aes Sedai's.

ɛɡwin sɝɾənli hæɾ oʊvɝlʊk ðɪs wʊmən! hu wɑz ʃi ɹɪli?

Egwene certainly had overlooked this woman! Who was she really?

"aɪ woʊn bi ə pɑɹɾi tə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ʌv ə ɡɝlz spɪɹət," lɑɹəz sɛd stɝnli. "ðoʊz biɾɪŋz ɑɹ ʃeɪmfəl! ful ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪv sɝv lɔɪəli ðiz jɪɹz, aɪ hæv, bʌt naʊ ðeɪv toʊl mi ðət jəɹ tə bi wɝkt əz hɑɹɾ əz aɪ kən pʊʃ ju, ɪndɛfənətli. wɛl, aɪ kən si wən ə ɡɝl əz muvd əweɪ fɹəm biɪŋ ɪnstʃɹʌktəɾ ən ɪndə biɪŋ biɾən daʊn. aɪ woʊn əv ɪt, nɑɾ ɪn maɪ kɪtʃənz. laɪt bɝn ɪleɪɾə fəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi kəd də sətʃ ə θɪŋ! ɛksəkjut jə əɹ meɪk jə ə nɑvəs, aɪ doʊn kɛɹ. bʌt ðɪs bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪz ʌnæksɛptəbəl!"

"I won't be a party to the breaking of a girl's spirit," Laras said sternly. "Those beatings are shameful! Fool Aes Sedai. I've served loyally these years, I have, but now they've told me that you're to be worked as hard as I can push you, indefinitely. Well, I can see when a girl has moved away from being instructed and into being beaten down. I won't have it, not in my kitchens. Light burn Elaida for thinking she could do such a thing! Execute you or make you a novice, I don't care. But this breaking is unacceptable!"

ðə wʊmən stʊd, sɛɾɪŋ hænz ɑn hɪps, ə pʌf ə flaʊɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm əɹ eɪpɹən. ɑdli, ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ði ɔfɝ. ʃid dɪnaɪd sɪuənz ɔfɝ tə seɪv hɝ, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi flɛd naʊ, ʃi wəd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə ɹɛbəl kæmp hævɪŋ fɹid hɝsɛlf. ðət wəd bi fɑɹ supɪɹiɝ tə biɪŋ ɹɛskjud. ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɔl ðɪs, əweɪ fɹəm ðə biɾɪŋz, əweɪ fɹəm ðə dʒɹʌdʒɝi.

The woman stood, setting hands on hips, a puff of flour rising from her apron. Oddly, Egwene found herself considering the offer. She'd denied Siuan's offer to save her, but if she fled now, she would return to the rebel camp having freed herself. That would be far superior to being rescued. She could get away from all this, away from the beatings, away from the drudgery.

tə də wʌt? tə sɪɾ ɑn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ən wɑtʃ ðə taʊɝ kəlæps?

To do what? To sit on the outside and watch the Tower collapse?

"noʊ," ʃi sɛd tə lɑɹəz. "jɔɹ ɔfɝ ɪz vɛɹi kaɪnd, bʌɾ aɪ kæn teɪk ɪt. aɪm sɑɹi."

"No," she said to Laras. "Your offer is very kind, but I can't take it. I'm sorry."

lɑɹəz fɹaʊnd. "naʊ, jə lɪsən - "

Laras frowned. "Now, you listen - "

"lɑɹəz," ɛɡwin ɪntɝʌptɪd, "wʌn dʌz nɑt teɪk ðət toʊn wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, noʊ mæɾɝ ðət wʌn ɪz ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə kɪtʃənz."

"Laras," Egwene interrupted, "one does not take that tone with an Aes Sedai, no matter that one is the Mistress of Kitchens."

lɑɹəz hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ful ɡɝl. jə eɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Laras hesitated. "Fool girl. You ain't Aes Sedai."

"æksɛpt ɪɾ əɹ nɑt, aɪ stɪl kænt ɡoʊ. ənlɛs jə ɪntɛn tə tʃɹaɪ stʌfɪŋ mi ɪndə ðət hoʊl jɝsɛlf -  ɡæɡɪŋ ən taɪɪŋ mi tə kip mi fɹəm kɹaɪɪŋ aʊt, fɑloʊd baɪ ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ mi əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪn pɝsən  - ðən aɪ sədʒɛs lɛɾɪŋ mi ɹɪtɝn tə maɪ wɝk."

"Accept it or not, I still can't go. Unless you intend to try stuffing me into that hole yourself -  gagging and tying me to keep me from crying out, followed by escorting me across the river in person  - then I suggest letting me return to my work."

"bʌt waɪ?"

"But why?"

"bɪkɔz," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ bæk ət ðə faɪɝpleɪs. "sʌmwʌn əz tə faɪt hɝ."

"Because," Egwene said, glancing back at the fireplace. "Someone has to fight her."

"ju kæn faɪt laɪk ðɪs," lɑɹəz sɛd.

"You can't fight like this," Laras said.

"itʃ deɪ ɪz ə bæɾəl," ɛɡwin sɛd. "itʃ deɪ aɪ ɹəfjuz tə bɛn minz sʌmθɪŋ. ivən ɪf ɪleɪɾə ən əɹ ɹɛdz ɑɹ ði oʊnli wʌnz u noʊ ɪt, ðæts sʌmθɪŋ. ə smɔl sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt mɔɹ ðən aɪ kəd də fɹəm ði aʊtsaɪd. kʌm. aɪv stɪl ɡɑt tu aʊɝz ʌv wɝk lɛft."

"Each day is a battle," Egwene said. "Each day I refuse to bend means something. Even if Elaida and her Reds are the only ones who know it, that's something. A small something, but more than I could do from the outside. Come. I've still got two hours of work left."

ʃi tɝn ən bɪɡæn tə wɔk bæk təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ə ɹɪlʌktən lɑɹəz kloʊz ðə hætʃ ɑn əɹ hɪɾən tʃeɪmbɝ, ðən dʒɔɪn hɝ. ðə wʊmən meɪd mʌtʃ mɔɹ nɔɪz naʊ əz ʃi wɔkt, bɹʌʃɪŋ əɡɛns kaʊntɝz, hɝ fʊtfɔlz saʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə bɹɪks. kjʊɹiəs haʊ ʃid bɪn eɪbəl tə bi soʊ kwaɪət wən ʃi wɑntəd tə.

She turned and began to walk back toward the fireplace. A reluctant Laras closed the hatch on her hidden chamber, then joined her. The woman made much more noise now as she walked, brushing against counters, her footfalls sounding on the bricks. Curious how she'd been able to be so quiet when she wanted to.

ə flæʃ ə ɹɛd klɔθ, laɪk ðə blʌɾ ʌv ə dɛd ɹæbəɾ ɪn ðə snoʊ, muv θɹu ðə kɪtʃənz.

A flash of red cloth, like the blood of a dead rabbit in the snow, moved through the kitchens.

ɛɡwin fɹoʊz əz keɪɾɝin, wɛɹɪŋ ə dʒɹɛs wɪð kɹɪmzən skɝts ən jɛloʊ tʃɹɪm, spɑɾəd hɝ. ðə ɹɛdz maʊθ wɑz θɪn-lɪpt, hɝ aɪz nɛɹoʊ. hæd ʃi sin ɛɡwin ən lɑɹəz wɔk ɔf?

Egwene froze as Katerine, wearing a dress with crimson skirts and yellow trim, spotted her. The Red's mouth was thin-lipped, her eyes narrow. Had she seen Egwene and Laras walk off?

lɑɹəz fɹoʊz.

Laras froze.

"aɪ si naʊ wʌɾ aɪ wɑz duɪŋ ɹɔŋ," ɛɡwin kwɪkli sɛd tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə kɪtʃənz, aɪɪŋ ə sɛkən hɑɹθ, wɪtʃ leɪ nɪɹ wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn stændɪŋ ɪn ðə pæntʃɹi. "θæŋk jə fəɹ ʃoʊɪŋ ɪt tə mi. əl bi mɔɹ kɛɹfəl naʊ."

"I see now what I was doing wrong," Egwene quickly said to the Mistress of Kitchens, eyeing a second hearth, which lay near where they had been standing in the pantry. "Thank you for showing it to me. I'll be more careful now."

"si ðət jə ɑɹ," lɑɹəz sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ ʃɑk. "ʌðɝwaɪz, jəl si wʌɾ ə ɹil pʌnɪʃmən ɪz laɪk, nɑt ðoʊz hæfhɑɹɾɪd pæɾəlɪŋz ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ɡɪvz. naʊ bæk tə wɝk wɪð ju."

"See that you are," Laras said, shaking out of her shock. "Otherwise, you'll see what a real punishment is like, not those halfhearted paddlings the Mistress of Novices gives. Now back to work with you."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd, hɝiɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝpleɪs. keɪɾɝin hɛld ʌp ə hæn tə fɔɹstɔl hɝ.

Egwene nodded, hurrying back toward the fireplace. Katerine held up a hand to forestall her.

ɛɡwinz hɑɹt θʌmp tʃɹeɪɾɝəsli.

Egwene's heart thumped traitorously.

"noʊ nid," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "ði æmɪɝlɪn əz dɪmændəd ðət ðə nɑvəs ətɛn əɹ tənaɪɾ ət dɪnɝ.

"No need," Katerine said. "The Amyrlin has demanded that the novice attend her tonight at dinner.

aɪ toʊl ði æmɪɝlɪn ðət wʌn deɪ ʌv wɝk wəd hɑɹdli bɹeɪk sʌmwʌn əz fulɪʃli stʌbɝn əz ðɪs tʃaɪld, bʌt ʃiz ɪnsɪstənt. aɪ ɡɛs jə ɑɹ tə bi ɡɪvən jəɹ fɝs tʃæns tə pɹuv jəɹ hjumɪlɪɾi, tʃaɪld. aɪ sədʒɛs jə teɪk ɪt."

I told the Amyrlin that one day of work would hardly break someone as foolishly stubborn as this child, but she is insistent. I guess you are to be given your first chance to prove your humility, child. I suggest you take it."

ɛɡwin ɡlæns daʊn əɾ əɹ blækən hænz ən sɔɪl dʒɹɛs.

Egwene glanced down at her blackened hands and soiled dress.

"ɡoʊ, ɹʌn," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "wɑʃ ʌp ən klin jɝsɛlf. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪl nɑt bi kɛpt weɪɾɪŋ."

"Go, run," Katerine said. "Wash up and clean yourself. The Amyrlin will not be kept waiting."

wɑʃɪŋ ʌp pɹuv tə bi nɪɹli əz dɪfəkəlt əz klinɪŋ ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ðə sʊt hæd steɪn əɹ hænz mʌtʃ ɪn ðə weɪ ɪt hæd ðə wɝk dʒɹɛs. ɛɡwin spɛn ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ən aʊɝ wɑʃɪŋ ɪn ə tʌb fʊl ə lukwɔɹm wɔɾɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk hɝsɛlf pɹəzɛntəbəl. hɝ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz wɝ ɹæɡəd fɹəm skɹeɪpɪŋ ðə bɹɪks, ən ɪt sim ðəɾ itʃ taɪm ʃi ɹɪnst əɹ hɛɹ, ʃi wɑʃt aʊɾ ən ɪntaɪɝ bʌkəts wɝθ ə sʊt fleɪks.

Washing up proved to be nearly as difficult as cleaning the fireplace. The soot had stained her hands much in the way it had the work dress. Egwene spent the better part of an hour washing in a tub full of lukewarm water, trying to make herself presentable. Her fingernails were ragged from scraping the bricks, and it seemed that each time she rinsed her hair, she washed out an entire bucket's worth of soot flakes.

haʊɛvɝ, ʃi wɑz ɡlæd fəɹ ðə tʃæns. ʃi ɹɛɹli hæd mʌtʃ taɪm fəɹ beɪðɪŋ; juʒəwəli ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə kwɪk skɹʌb. əz ʃi ɹɪnst ən skɹʌbd ɪn ðə smɔl, ɡɹeɪ-taɪl beɪðɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ, ʃi kənsɪɾɝd əɹ nɛkst stɛp.

However, she was glad for the chance. She rarely had much time for bathing; usually she could not stop for more than a quick scrub. As she rinsed and scrubbed in the small, gray-tiled bathing chamber, she considered her next step.

ʃi hæd tɝn daʊn ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə fli. ðət mɛnt ʃi hæd tə wɝk wɪð ɪleɪɾə ən əɹ ɹɛdz, ði oʊnli sɪstɝz ʃi sɔ. bʌt kəd ðeɪ bi meɪd tə si ðɛɹ ɛɹɝz? ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd sɛn ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm fəɹ pɛnəns ən bi ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm.

She had turned down the opportunity to flee. That meant she had to work with Elaida and her Reds, the only sisters she saw. But could they be made to see their errors? She wished she could send the whole lot of them for penance and be rid of them.

bʌt noʊ. ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn; ʃi ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾ ɔl ədʒəz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə ɹɛd. ʃi kʊdn tʃɹiɾ əm əz ɪleɪɾə hæd tʃɹiɾəd ðə bluz. ðeɪ wɝ ðə moʊst æntæɡənɪstɪk təwɔɹd hɝ, bʌt ðət mɛn ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ tʃælənʒ. ʃi sim tə bi meɪkɪŋ səm hɛdweɪ wɪð sɪlviænə, ən hædn lɹin dɔɪɹɛlɪn ədmɪɾəd ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə hæd meɪd sɪɹiəs mɪsteɪks?

But no. She was Amyrlin; she represented all Ajahs, including the Red. She couldn't treat them as Elaida had treated the Blues. They were the most antagonistic toward her, but that meant a greater challenge. She seemed to be making some headway with Silviana, and hadn't Lirene Doirellin admitted that Elaida had made serious mistakes?

meɪbi ðə ɹɛdz wɝn ði oʊnli wʌnz ʃi kəɾ ɪnfluəns. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz tʃæns miɾɪŋz wɪð ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz. ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm əpɹoʊtʃt əɹ tə spik, ðə ɹɛdz kʊdn vɛɹi wɛl toʊ hɝ əweɪ. ðeɪ wəd ʃoʊ səm dɪkɔɹəm, ən ðət wəd ɡɪv ɛɡwin ə tʃæns tə ɪntɝækt ə bɪt wɪð ʌðɝ sɪstɝz.

Maybe the Reds weren't the only ones she could influence. There were always chance meetings with other sisters in the hallways. If one of them approached her to speak, the Reds couldn't very well tow her away. They would show some decorum, and that would give Egwene a chance to interact a bit with other sisters.

bʌt haʊ tə tʃɹiɾ ɪleɪɾə hɝsɛlf? wɑz ɪt waɪz tə lɛt ðə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn kəntɪnju tə θɪŋk ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz nɪɹli kaʊd? əɹ wɑz ɪt taɪm tə meɪk ə stænd?

But how to treat Elaida herself? Was it wise to let the false Amyrlin continue to think that Egwene was nearly cowed? Or was it time to make a stand?

baɪ ði ɛn ə hɝ bæθ, ɛɡwin fɛlt ə ɡɹeɪt dil klinɝ ən ə ɡɹeɪt dil mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt. hɝ wɔɹ hæd teɪkən ə sɪɹiəs tɝn fəɹ ðə wɝs, bʌt ʃi kəd stɪl faɪt. ʃi ɹæn ə hɝid bɹʌʃ θɹu hɝ wɛt hɛɹ, θɹu ɑn ə nu nɑvəs dʒɹɛs - maɪ, haʊ ɡʊɾ ɪt fɛl tə hæv ðə sɑft, klin fæbɹɪk ɑn əɹ skɪn! - ən lɛf tə dʒɔɪn əɹ hænlɝz.

By the end of her bath, Egwene felt a great deal cleaner and a great deal more confident. Her war had taken a serious turn for the worse, but she could still fight. She ran a hurried brush through her wet hair, threw on a new novice dress - my, how good it felt to have the soft, clean fabric on her skin! - and left to join her handlers.

ðeɪ ɛskɔɹɾɪd əɹ ʌp tə ði æmɪɝlɪnz tʃeɪmbɝz. ɛɡwin pæst sɛvɹəl ɡɹups ə sɪstɝz, ən ʃi hɛl hɝsɛlf kɛɹfəli ɪɹɛk fəɹ ðɛɹ bɛnəfɪt. ðə hænlɝz tʊk əɹ θɹu ðə ɹɛd sɛktɝ ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə taɪlz ɑn ðə flɔɹ ʃɪftɪŋ tə ə pæɾɝn ə ɹɛɾ ən tʃɑɹkoʊl. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ pipəl wɔkɪŋ əbaʊt hɪɹ, wɪmən ɪn ðɛɹ ʃɔlz, sɝvəns bɛɹɪŋ ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts.

They escorted her up to the Amyrlin's chambers. Egwene passed several groups of sisters, and she held herself carefully erect for their benefit. The handlers took her through the Red sector of the Tower, the tiles on the floor shifting to a pattern of red and charcoal. There were more people walking about here, women in their shawls, servants bearing the Flame of Tar Valon on their chests.

nɛvɝ ɛni wɔɹɾɝz; ðəɾ ɔlweɪz fɛl stʃɹeɪnʒ tə ɛɡwin, sɪns ðeɪ wɝ soʊ kɑmən ɪn ʌðɝ pɑɹts ə ðə taʊɝ.

Never any Warders; that always felt strange to Egwene, since they were so common in other parts of the Tower.

ə lɔŋ klaɪm ən ə fju twɪsts leɪɾɝ, ðeɪ ɝaɪvd əɾ ɪleɪɾəz kɔɹɾɝz. ɛɡwin tʃɛkt əɹ skɝts ʌnkɑnʃəsli. ʃi hæd dɪtɝmən dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔk ðət ʃi niɾəd tə əpɹoʊtʃ ɪleɪɾə wɪð saɪləns, dʒʌst əz ʃi hæd læs taɪm. ɹaɪlɪŋ əɹ fɝðɝ wəɾ oʊnli lɛd tə mɔɹ ɹistʃɹɪkʃənz. ɛɡwin wəd nɑt dəbeɪs hɝsɛlf, bʌt niðɝ wəd ʃi ɡoʊ aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ tə ɪnsʌlt ɪleɪɾə. lɛt ðə wʊmən θɪŋk əz ʃi wɪʃt.

A long climb and a few twists later, they arrived at Elaida's quarters. Egwene checked her skirts unconsciously. She had determined during the walk that she needed to approach Elaida with silence, just as she had last time. Riling her further would only lead to more restrictions. Egwene would not debase herself, but neither would she go out of her way to insult Elaida. Let the woman think as she wished.

ə sɝvən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, liɾɪŋ ɛɡwin ɪn, ən ɪndə ðə daɪnɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ. ðɛɹ, ʃi wɑz ʃɑk baɪ wʌt ʃi faʊnd. ʃi hæɾ əsumd ʃiɾ ətɛn ɪleɪɾə əloʊn, əɹ meɪbi wɪð maɪdɑni.

A servant opened the door, leading Egwene in, and into the dining chamber. There, she was shocked by what she found. She had assumed she'd attend Elaida alone, or maybe with Meidani.

ɛɡwin hædn fəɹ ə moʊmən kənsɪɾɝd ðət ðə daɪnɪŋ ɹum wəd bi fɪld wɪð wɪmən. ðəɹ wɝ faɪv, wʌn fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ seɪv ðə ɹɛɾ ən ðə blu. ən itʃ wʊmən wɑz ə sɪɾɝ. jukɪɝi wɑz ðɛɹ, əz wɑz dʌsin, boʊθ fɹəm ðə klændɛstɪn hʌntɝz ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ. fɛɹən wɑz ðɛɹ, ðoʊ ʃi sim sɝpɹaɪz tə si ɛɡwin; hæd ðə waɪt nɑt noʊn əbaʊt ðɪs dɪnɝ ɝliɝ, əɹ hæd ʃi sɪmpli nɑt mɛnʃən ɪt?

Egwene hadn't for a moment considered that the dining room would be filled with women. There were five, one from each Ajah save the Red and the Blue. And each woman was a Sitter. Yukiri was there, as was Doesine, both from the clandestine hunters of the Black Ajah. Ferane was there, though she seemed surprised to see Egwene; had the White not known about this dinner earlier, or had she simply not mentioned it?

ɹubɪnd, ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, sæt bɪsaɪd ʃɛvən ə ðə bɹaʊn, ə sɪstɝ hum ɛɡwin hæd bɪn wɑntɪŋ tə mit. ʃɛvən wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u səpɔɹɾəd nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ɛɡwin hoʊp tə bi eɪbəl tə nʌdʒ əɹ mɔɹ təwɔɹd hɛlpɪŋ junəfaɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ fɹəm wɪðɪn.

Rubinde, of the Green Ajah, sat beside Shevan of the Brown, a sister whom Egwene had been wanting to meet. Shevan was one of those who supported negotiating with the rebel Aes Sedai, and Egwene hoped to be able to nudge her more toward helping unify the White Tower from within.

ðəɹ wɑzn ə ɹɛd sɪstɝ ət ðə teɪbəl ʌðɝ ðən ɪleɪɾə. wɑz ðət kəz ðə ɹɛd sɪɾɝz wɝ ɔl aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ? pɝhæps ɪleɪɾə θɔt ðə ɹum bælənst wɪð əɹ ðɛɹ, əz ʃi stɪl θɔɾ ə hɝsɛlf əz ɹɛd, ɔlðoʊ ʃi wɑzn səpoʊz tə.

There wasn't a Red sister at the table other than Elaida. Was that because the Red Sitters were all out of the Tower? Perhaps Elaida thought the room balanced with her there, as she still thought of herself as Red, although she wasn't supposed to.

ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ teɪbəl, kɹɪstəl ɡoʊbləts spɑɹklɪŋ ən ɹəflɛktɪŋ laɪt fɹəm ði ɔɹneɪt bɹɑnz stændlæmps, ɹʌnɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz peɪntəɾ ə ɹʌsti ɹɛd-jɛloʊ ɪn kʌlɝ. itʃ wʊmən wɔɹ ə faɪn ɡaʊn ɪn ðə kʌlɝ ə hɝ ədʒɑ. ðə ɹum smɛld ə sʌkjəlɪn mits ən stim kæɹəts. ðə wɪmən tʃæɾəd. æmɪkəbəl, bʌt fɔɹst. tɛns. ðeɪ dɪdnt wɑnə bi ðɛɹ.

It was a long table, crystal goblets sparkling and reflecting light from the ornate bronze standlamps, running along the walls painted a rusty red-yellow in color. Each woman wore a fine gown in the color of her Ajah. The room smelled of succulent meats and steamed carrots. The women chatted. Amicable, but forced. Tense. They didn't want to be there.

əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, dʌsin nɑɾəd tə ɛɡwin, ɔlmoʊst ɪn ɹɪspɛkt. ɪt wɑz ən ɪndəkeɪʃən ə sʌmθɪŋ. "aɪm hɪɹ kəz jə sɛd ðət ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt," ɪt sim tə seɪ. ɪleɪɾə sæɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə teɪbəl, wɛɹɪŋ ə ɹɛd dʒɹɛs wɪð fʊl slivz, ʌnkʌt ɡɑɹnəts tʃɹɪmɪŋ əm ən ðə bɑɾəs, hɝ feɪs bɛɹɪŋ ə sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl. sɝvəns bʌsəl bæk ən fɔɹθ, pɔɹɪŋ waɪn ən bɹɪŋɪŋ fud. waɪ hæɾ ɪleɪɾə kɔld ə dɪnɝ ə sɪɾɝz? wɑz ðɪs ən ətɛmp tə hil ðə ɹɪfs ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ? hæɾ ɛɡwin mɪsdʒʌdʒ hɝ?

Across the room, Doesine nodded to Egwene, almost in respect. It was an indication of something. "I'm here because you said that this sort of thing was important," it seemed to say. Elaida sat at the head of the table, wearing a red dress with full sleeves, uncut garnets trimming them and the bodice, her face bearing a satisfied smile. Servants bustled back and forth, pouring wine and bringing food. Why had Elaida called a dinner of Sitters? Was this an attempt to heal the rifts in the White Tower? Had Egwene misjudged her?

"ɑ, ɡʊd," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, noʊɾɪsɪŋ ɛɡwin. "juv faɪnəli ɝaɪvd. kʌm hɪɹ, tʃaɪld."

"Ah, good," Elaida said, noticing Egwene. "You've finally arrived. Come here, child."

ɛɡwin dɪd soʊ, wɔkɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹum, ðə læs fju sɪɾɝz kætʃɪŋ noʊɾəs ə hɝ. səm sim kənfjuzd, ʌðɝz meɪd kjʊɹiəs, baɪ hɝ pɹɛzəns. əz ʃi wɔkt, ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz sʌmθɪŋ.

Egwene did so, walking through the room, the last few Sitters catching notice of her. Some seemed confused, others made curious, by her presence. As she walked, Egwene realized something.

ðɪs wʌn ivnɪŋ kəɾ izəli əndu ɔl ðət ʃid wɝk fɔɹ.

This one evening could easily undo all that she'd worked for.

ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ sɔ hɝ sʌbsɝvinli weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪleɪɾə, ɛɡwin wəd luz ɪntɛɡɹəɾi ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. ɪleɪɾə hæd dɪklɛɹd ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz kaʊd - bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd pɹuvən ʌðɝwaɪz. ɪf ʃi bɛn tə ɪleɪɾəz wɪl hɪɹ, ivən ə lɪɾəl, ɪt wəd bi sin əz pɹuf.

If the Aes Sedai here saw her subserviently waiting on Elaida, Egwene would lose integrity in their eyes. Elaida had declared that Egwene was cowed - but Egwene had proven otherwise. If she bent to Elaida's will here, even a little, it would be seen as proof.

laɪt bɝn ðə wʊmən! waɪ hæd ʃi ɪnvaɪɾəd soʊ mɛni ʌv ðə wɪmən ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ tə ɪnfluəns? wɑz ɪt sɪmpəl hæpənstæns? ɛɡwin dʒɔɪn ðə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə teɪbəl, ən ə sɝvən hændəɾ əɹ ə kɹɪstəl pɪtʃɝ ʌv ɡlɪsnɪŋ ɹɛd waɪn. "ju ɑɹ tə kip maɪ kʌp fʊl,"

Light burn the woman! Why had she invited so many of the women that Egwene had been working to influence? Was it simple happenstance? Egwene joined the false Amyrlin at the head of the table, and a servant handed her a crystal pitcher of glistening red wine. "You are to keep my cup full,"

ɪleɪɾə sɛd. "weɪt ðɛɹ, bʌt doʊn kʌm tu kloʊs. aɪd ɹæðɝ nɑɾ əv tə smɛl ðə sʊɾ ɑn jə fɹəm jəɹ pʌnɪʃməns ðɪs æftɝnun."

Elaida said. "Wait there, but don't come too close. I'd rather not have to smell the soot on you from your punishments this afternoon."

ɛɡwin klɛntʃt əɹ dʒɔ. smɛl ðə sʊt? æftɝ ən aʊɝ ə skɹʌbɪŋ? daʊtfəl. fɹəm ðə saɪd, ʃi kəd si ðə sæɾəsfækʃən ɪn ɪleɪɾəz aɪz əz ʃi sɪpt əɹ waɪn. ðən ɪleɪɾə tɝn tə ʃɛvən, hu sæɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ tə ɪleɪɾəz ɹaɪt. ðə bɹaʊn wɑz ə læŋki wʊmən, wɪð nɑbd ɑɹmz ən ən æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs, laɪk ə pɝsən meɪɾ ə nɑɹl stɪks. hɝ aɪz wɝ θɔtfəl əz ʃi stʌɾid əɹ hoʊstəs.

Egwene clenched her jaw. Smell the soot? After an hour of scrubbing? Doubtful. From the side, she could see the satisfaction in Elaida's eyes as she sipped her wine. Then Elaida turned to Shevan, who sat in the chair to Elaida's right. The Brown was a lanky woman, with knobbed arms and an angular face, like a person made of gnarled sticks. Her eyes were thoughtful as she studied her hostess.

"tɛl mi, ʃɛvən," ɪleɪɾə sɛd. "du jə stɪl ɪnsɪst ɑn ðoʊz fulɪʃ tɔks wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz?"

"Tell me, Shevan," Elaida said. "Do you still insist on those foolish talks with the rebels?"

ʃɛvən ɹɪspɑndɪd. "ðə sɪstɝz mʌs bi ɡɪvən ə tʃæns tə ɹɛkənsaɪl."

Shevan responded. "The sisters must be given a chance to reconcile."

"ðeɪv hæd ðɛɹ tʃæns," ɪleɪɾə sɛd. "ɑnəsli, aɪ ɪkspɛktəd mɔɹ ʌv ə bɹaʊn. jəɹ bɪheɪvɪŋ dɔɡədli, wɪθaʊɾ ə wɪɾ ʌv ʌndɝstændɪŋ haʊ ðə ɹil wɝld wɝks. waɪ, ivən maɪdɑni əɡɹiz wɪð mi, ən ʃiz ə ɡɹeɪ! jə noʊ haʊ ðeɪ ɑɹ."

"They've had their chance," Elaida said. "Honestly, I expected more of a Brown. You're behaving doggedly, without a whit of understanding how the real world works. Why, even Meidani agrees with me, and she's a Gray! You know how they are."

ʃɛvən tɝn əweɪ, simɪŋ mɔɹ dɪstɝb ðən bɪfɔɹ. waɪ dɪɾ ɪleɪɾə ɪnvaɪɾ əm tə dɪnɝ, ɪf oʊnli tə ɪnsʌlt əm ən ðɛɹ ədʒəz? əz ɛɡwin wɑtʃt, ðə ɹɛd tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə fɛɹən, ən kəmpleɪn tə hɝ əbaʊt ɹubɪnd, ə sɪɾɝ fɹəm ðə ɡɹin u ɔlsoʊ ɹɪzɪstɪɾ ɪleɪɾəz ɛfɝts tə ɛn ðə tɔks. əz ʃi spoʊk, ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ kʌp tə ɛɡwin, tæpɪŋ ɪt. ɪleɪɾə hæd bɛɹli teɪkən ə fju sɪps.

Shevan turned away, seeming more disturbed than before. Why did Elaida invite them to dinner, if only to insult them and their Ajahs? As Egwene watched, the Red turned her attention to Ferane, and complained to her about Rubinde, a Sitter from the Green who also resisted Elaida's efforts to end the talks. As she spoke, she raised her cup to Egwene, tapping it. Elaida had barely taken a few sips.

ɛɡwin ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ, fɪlɪŋ ðə kʌp. ði ʌðɝz hæd sin əɹ də leɪbɝ bɪfɔɹ - waɪ, ʃid kɹækt wɔlnʌts fəɹ fɛɹən. ðɪs wʊdn ɹuən əɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən, nɑɾ ənlɛs ɪleɪɾə fɔɹst əɹ tə əbeɪs hɝsɛlf sʌmhaʊ.

Egwene ground her teeth, filling the cup. The others had seen her do labor before - why, she'd cracked walnuts for Ferane. This wouldn't ruin her reputation, not unless Elaida forced her to abase herself somehow.

bʌt wʌt wɑz ðə pɔɪn ə ðɪs dɪnɝ? ɪleɪɾə dɪdn sim tə bi meɪkɪŋ ɛni ətɛmp tə bɹɪŋ ði ədʒəz təɡɛðɝ. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ʃi wɑz pɹaɪɪŋ ðoʊz ɹɪfs waɪɾɝ, ðə weɪ ʃi wɑz dɪsmɪsɪŋ ðoʊz u dɪsəɡɹid wɪð hɝ. əkeɪʒənəli, ʃi wəɾ əv ɛɡwin ɹifɪl əɹ kʌp, bʌɾ ɪt nɛvɝ hæd ɹum fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə sɪp əɹ tu.

But what was the point of this dinner? Elaida didn't seem to be making any attempt to bring the Ajahs together. If anything, she was prying those rifts wider, the way she was dismissing those who disagreed with her. Occasionally, she would have Egwene refill her cup, but it never had room for more than a sip or two.

sloʊli, ɛɡwin bɪɡæn tə ʌndɝstænd. ðɪs dɪnɝ wɑzn əbaʊt wɝkɪŋ wɪð ði ədʒəz. ɪt wɑz əbaʊt bʊliɪŋ ðə sɪɾɝz ɪndə duɪŋ əz ɪleɪɾə fɛl ðeɪ ʃʊd. ən ɛɡwin wɑz sɪmpli ðəɹ tə bi ʃoʊn ɔf! ðɪs wɑz ɔl əbaʊt pɹuvɪŋ tə ði ʌðɝz haʊ mʌtʃ paʊɝ ɪleɪɾə hæd - ʃi kəd teɪk sʌmwʌn ðəɾ ʌðɝz hæd neɪmd æmɪɝlɪn, pʊɾ ə nɑvəs dʒɹɛs ɑn əɹ ən sɛn əɹ tə pɛnəns ɛvɹi deɪ.

Slowly, Egwene began to understand. This dinner wasn't about working with the Ajahs. It was about bullying the Sitters into doing as Elaida felt they should. And Egwene was simply there to be shown off! This was all about proving to the others how much power Elaida had - she could take someone that others had named Amyrlin, put a novice dress on her and send her to penance every day.

ɛɡwin fɛl hɝsɛlf ɡɹoʊ æŋɡɹi əɡɛn. waɪ kəɾ ɪleɪɾə ɔlweɪz stɝ əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz? sup boʊlz wɝ ɹimuvd ən pleɪts ə stimd, bʌɾɝd kæɹəts wɝ bɹɔt, ə hɪn ə sɪnəmən stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ði ɛɹ. ɛɡwin hæd nɑt bɪn ɡɪvən dɪnɝ, bʌt ʃi fɛl tu sɪk tə kɛɹ əbaʊɾ iɾɪŋ.

Egwene felt herself grow angry again. Why could Elaida always stir her emotions? Soup bowls were removed and plates of steamed, buttered carrots were brought, a hint of cinnamon striking the air. Egwene had not been given dinner, but she felt too sick to care about eating.

noʊ, ʃi θɔt, stilɪŋ hɝsɛlf. əl nɑɾ ɛn ðɪs ɝli, laɪk læs taɪm. əl ɛndʒjʊɹ. aɪm stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɪleɪɾə. aɪm stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən əɹ mædnəs.

No, she thought, steeling herself. I will not end this early, like last time. I will endure. I am stronger than Elaida. I'm stronger than her madness.

ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən kəntɪnjud, ɪleɪɾə meɪkɪŋ ɪnsʌltɪŋ kɑmɛns tə ði ʌðɝz, səmtaɪmz wɪð ɪntɛnt, səmtaɪmz wɪð əpɛɹən ənəwɛɹnəs. ði ʌðɝz stɪɹd ðə tɔk əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɛbəlz ən təwɔɹd ðə stʃɹeɪnʒli oʊvɝkæst skaɪz. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʃɛvən mɛnʃən ə ɹumɝ əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn wɝkɪŋ wɪð il fɑɹ tə ðə saʊθ.

The conversation continued, Elaida making insulting comments to the others, sometimes with intent, sometimes with apparent unawareness. The others steered the talk away from the rebels and toward the strangely overcast skies. Eventually, Shevan mentioned a rumor about the Seanchan working with Aiel far to the south.

"ðə sintʃæn əɡɛn?" ɪleɪɾə sɛd wɪð ə saɪ. "ju nidnt wɝi əbaʊt ðɛm."

"The Seanchan again?" Elaida said with a sigh. "You needn't worry about them."

"maɪ sɔɹsəz seɪ ʌðɝwaɪz, mʌðɝ," ʃɛvən sɛd stɪfli. "aɪ θɪŋk wi nid tə peɪ kloʊs ətɛnʃən tə wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ duɪŋ. aɪ hæv hæd səm sɪstɝz æsk ðɪs tʃaɪld əbaʊɾ əɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð ðɛm, wɪtʃ əz bɪn ɪkstɛnsɪv. jə ʃəd hɪɹ ðə θɪŋz ðeɪ də tə ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"My sources say otherwise, Mother," Shevan said stiffly. "I think we need to pay close attention to what they are doing. I have had some sisters ask this child about her experience with them, which has been extensive. You should hear the things they do to Aes Sedai."

ɪleɪɾə læft ə tɪŋkəlɪŋ, məlɑɾɪk læf. "ʃʊɹli jə noʊ haʊ ðə tʃaɪld ɪz pɹoʊn tə ɪɡzædʒɝeɪt!"

Elaida laughed a tinkling, melodic laugh. "Surely you know how the child is prone to exaggerate!"

ʃi ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin. "hæv jə bɪn spɹɛɾɪŋ laɪz fəɹ jəɹ fɹɛnd, ðə ful ælθɹ? wʌɾ i tɛl jə tə seɪ əbaʊt ðiz ɪnveɪɾɝz? ðeɪ ɑɹ wɝkɪŋ fəɹ hɪm, ɑɹ ðeɪ nɑt?"

She glanced at Egwene. "Have you been spreading lies for your friend, the fool al'Thor? What did he tell you to say about these invaders? They are working for him, are they not?"

ɛɡwin dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd.

Egwene didn't respond.

"spik," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð əɹ kʌp. "tɛl ðiz wɪmən juv bɪn spikɪŋ laɪz.

"Speak," Elaida said, gesturing with her cup. "Tell these women you have been speaking lies.

kənfɛs əɹ əl əv jə ɪn pɛnəns əɡɛn, ɡɝl."

Confess or I'll have you in penance again, girl."

ðə pɛnəns ʃi wəd teɪk fəɹ nɑt spikɪŋ wəd bi bɛɾɝ ðən sʌfɝɪŋ ɪleɪɾəz ɹeɪdʒ ət kɑntʃɹədɪktɪŋ hɝ. saɪləns wɑz ðə pæθ tə vɪktɝi.

The penance she would take for not speaking would be better than suffering Elaida's rage at contradicting her. Silence was the path to victory.

ən jɛt, əz ɛɡwin ɡlæns daʊn ðə lɔŋ məhɑɡəni teɪbəl, sɛt wɪð bɹaɪt waɪt si foʊk pɔɹsələn ən flɪkɝɪŋ ɹɛd kændəlz, ʃi sɔ faɪv pɛɹz ʌv aɪz stʌɾiɪŋ hɝ. ʃi kəd si ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz. ɛɡwin hæd spoʊkən boʊldli tə ðɛm wən əloʊn, bʌt wəd ʃi hoʊl tə hɝ əsɝʃənz naʊ, feɪs baɪ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wʊmən ɪn ðə wɝld? ə wʊmən u hɛld ɛɡwinz laɪf ɪn əɹ hænz?

And yet, as Egwene glanced down the long mahogany table, set with bright white Sea Folk porcelain and flickering red candles, she saw five pairs of eyes studying her. She could see their questions. Egwene had spoken boldly to them when alone, but would she hold to her assertions now, faced by the most powerful woman in the world? A woman who held Egwene's life in her hands?

wɑz ɛɡwin ði æmɪɝlɪn? əɹ wɑz ʃi dʒʌst ə ɡɝl u laɪk tə pɹitɛnd?

Was Egwene the Amyrlin? Or was she just a girl who liked to pretend?

laɪt bɝn ju, ɪleɪɾə, ʃi θɔt, ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ, siɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ. saɪləns wʊdn lɛd tə vɪktɝi, nɑɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðiz wɪmən. jə ɑɹ nɑt gɑnə laɪk haʊ ðɪs pɹoʊsidz.

Light burn you, Elaida, she thought, gritting her teeth, seeing that she had been wrong. Silence wouldn't lead to victory, not in front of these women. You are not going to like how this proceeds.

"ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ nɑt wɝkɪŋ fəɹ ɹænd," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn ðeɪ ɑɹ ə səvɪɹ deɪnʒɝ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. aɪ hæv spɹɛd noʊ laɪz. tə seɪ ʌðɝwaɪz wəd bi tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ðə θɹi oʊðz."

"The Seanchan are not working for Rand," Egwene said. "And they are a severe danger to the White Tower. I have spread no lies. To say otherwise would be to betray the Three Oaths."

"ju hævən teɪkən ðə θɹi oʊðz," ɪleɪɾə sɛd stɝnli, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd hɝ.

"You haven't taken the Three Oaths," Elaida said sternly, turning toward her.

"aɪ hæv," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪv hɛl noʊ oʊθ ɹɑd, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪzən ðə ɹɑd ðət meɪks maɪ wɝdz tʃɹu. aɪ hæv spoʊkən ðə wɝdz ə ði oʊðz ɪn maɪ hɑɹt, ən tə mi ðeɪ ɑɹ mɔɹ dɪɹ, fəɹ aɪ hæv nʌθɪŋ fɔɹsɪŋ mi tə hoʊl tə ðɛm. ən baɪ ðəɾ oʊθ hoʊldɪŋ mi, aɪ tɛl jə əɡɛn. aɪm ə dʒɹimɝ, ən aɪ hæv dʒɹim ðət ðə sintʃæn wɪl ətæk ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"I have," Egwene said. "I've held no Oath Rod, but it isn't the Rod that makes my words true. I have spoken the words of the oaths in my heart, and to me they are more dear, for I have nothing forcing me to hold to them. And by that oath holding me, I tell you again. I am a Dreamer, and I have Dreamed that the Seanchan will attack the White Tower."

ɪleɪɾəz aɪz flɛɹd fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən ʃi ɡɹɪpt əɹ fɔɹk əntɪl əɹ nʌkəlz waɪɾənd. ɛɡwin hɛld əɹ aɪz, ən faɪnəli ɪleɪɾə læft əɡɛn. "ɑ, stʌbɝn əz ɛvɝ, aɪ si. aɪ ʃæl əv tə tɛl keɪɾɝin ðət ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt. jəl əv pɛnəns fəɹ jəɹ ɪɡzædʒɝeɪʃənz, tʃaɪld."

Elaida's eyes flared for a moment, and she gripped her fork until her knuckles whitened. Egwene held her eyes, and finally Elaida laughed again. "Ah, stubborn as ever, I see. I shall have to tell Katerine that she was right. You'll have penance for your exaggerations, child."

"ðiz wɪmən noʊ aɪ doʊn spik laɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd kɑmli. "æn itʃ taɪm jə ɪnsɪs ðəɾ aɪ du, jə loʊɝ jɝsɛlf ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. ivən ɪf jə dɪsbəliv maɪ dʒɹim, jə mʌst ədmɪt ðət ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ ə θɹɛt. ðeɪ liʃ wɪmən u kən tʃænəl, juzɪŋ əm əz wɛpənz wɪð ə kaɪndə twɪstəd tɛɹæŋɡɹil. aɪ hæv fɛl ðə kɑlɝ ɑn maɪ nɛk. aɪ stɪl fil ɪt, səmtaɪmz. ɪn maɪ dʒɹimz. maɪ naɪtmɛɹz."

"These women know I don't speak lies," Egwene said calmly. "And each time you insist that I do, you lower yourself in their eyes. Even if you disbelieve my Dream, you must admit that the Seanchan are a threat. They leash women who can channel, using them as weapons with a kind of twisted ter'angreal. I have felt the collar on my neck. I still feel it, sometimes. In my dreams. My nightmares."

ðə ɹum fɛl stɪl.

The room fell still.

"ju ɑɹ ə fulɪʃ tʃaɪld," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, ɑbviəsli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛn ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz noʊ θɹɛt.

"You are a foolish child," Elaida said, obviously trying to pretend that Egwene was no threat.

ʃi ʃʊɾə tɝn tə lʊk ət ði aɪz ə ði ʌðɝz. ɪf ʃi hæd, ʃiɾ əv sin ðə tʃɹuθ. "wɛl, juv fɔɹs maɪ hænd. jəl nil bɪfɔɹ mi, tʃaɪld, ən bɛɡ fɝɡɪvnəs. ɹaɪt naʊ.

She should have turned to look at the eyes of the others. If she had, she'd have seen the truth. "Well, you have forced my hand. You will kneel before me, child, and beg forgiveness. Right now.

ʌðɝwaɪz, əl lɑk jə əweɪ əloʊn. ɪz ðət wʌt jə wɑnt? doʊn θɪŋk ðət ðə biɾɪŋz wɪl stɑp, haʊɛvɝ. jəl stɪl ɡɛt jəɹ deɪli pɛnəns, jəl dʒʌs bi θɹoʊn bæk ɪndə jəɹ sɛl æftɝ itʃ wʌn.

Otherwise, I will lock you away alone. Is that what you want? Don't think that the beatings will stop, however. You'll still get your daily penance, you'll just be thrown back into your cell after each one.

naʊ, nil ən bɛɡ fɝɡɪvnəs."

Now, kneel and beg forgiveness."

ðə sɪɾɝz ɡlænst ət wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bækɪŋ daʊn naʊ. ɛɡwin wɪʃt ɪt hædn kʌm tə ðɪs. bʌɾ ɪt hæd, ən ɪleɪɾə hæd dɪmændəɾ ə faɪt.

The Sitters glanced at one another. There was no backing down now. Egwene wished it hadn't come to this. But it had, and Elaida had demanded a fight.

ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɡɪv əɹ wʌn. "æn ɪf aɪ də nɑt baʊ bɪfɔɹ ju?" ɛɡwin æskt, miɾɪŋ ðə wʊmənz aɪz. "wʌt ðɛn?"

It was time to give her one. "And if I do not bow before you?" Egwene asked, meeting the woman's eyes. "What then?"

"ju wɪl nil, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ," ɪleɪɾə ɡɹaʊld, ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs.

"You will kneel, one way or another," Elaida growled, embracing the Source.

"jul juz ðə paʊɝ ɑn mi?" ɛɡwin æskt kɑmli. "du juv tə ɹɪzɔɹt tə ðæt? hæv jə noʊ əθɔɹəɾi wɪθaʊt tʃænəlɪŋ?"

"You'll use the Power on me?" Egwene asked calmly. "Do you have to resort to that? Have you no authority without channeling?"

ɪleɪɾə pɔzd. "ɪɾ ɪz wɪðɪn maɪ ɹaɪts tə dɪsəplən wʌn u ɪzənt ʃoʊɪŋ pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɛkt."

Elaida paused. "It is within my rights to discipline one who isn't showing proper respect."

"æn soʊ jəl meɪk mi oʊbeɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪz ðɪs wʌt jəl də tə ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ɪleɪɾə? ən ədʒɑ əpoʊzɪz ju, ən ɪts dɪsbændɪd. sʌmwʌn dɪsplisɪz ju, ən jə tʃɹaɪ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɝ ɹaɪt tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. jəl əv ɛvɹi sɪstɝ boʊɪŋ daʊn bɪfɔɹ jə baɪ ði ɛn ə ðɪs."

"And so you will make me obey," Egwene said. "Is this what you will do to everyone in the Tower, Elaida? An Ajah opposes you, and it is disbanded. Someone displeases you, and you try to destroy her right to be Aes Sedai. You will have every sister bowing down before you by the end of this."

"nɑnsɛns!"

"Nonsense!"

"oʊ?" ɛɡwin æskt. "æn əv jə toʊld əm əbaʊt jəɹ aɪdiə fəɹ ə nu oʊθ? swɔɹn ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd baɪ ɛvɹi sɪstɝ, ən oʊθ tə oʊbeɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn ən səpɔɹt hɝ?"

"Oh?" Egwene asked. "And have you told them about your idea for a new oath? Sworn on the Oath Rod by every sister, an oath to obey the Amyrlin and support her?"

"aɪ - "

"I - "

"dɪnaɪ ɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "dɪnaɪ ðət jə meɪd ðə steɪtmənt. wɪl ði oʊðz lɛt ju?"

"Deny it," Egwene said. "Deny that you made the statement. Will the Oaths let you?"

ɪleɪɾə fɹoʊz. ɪf ʃi wɝ blæk, ʃi kəd dɪnaɪ ɪt, oʊθ ɹɑɾ əɹ nɑt. bʌɾ iðɝ weɪ, maɪdɑni kəd səbstæntʃieɪt wʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd sɛd.

Elaida froze. If she were Black, she could deny it, Oath Rod or not. But either way, Meidani could substantiate what Egwene had said.

"ɪt wɑz aɪɾəl tɔk," ɪleɪɾə sɛd. "dʒʌst spɛkjəleɪʃən, θɔts spoʊkən aʊt laʊd."

"It was idle talk," Elaida said. "Just speculation, thoughts spoken out loud."

"ðɛɹ ɪz ɔfən tʃɹuθ ɪn spɛkjəleɪʃən," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ju lɑk ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə bɑks; jə dʒʌs θɹɛɾənd tə də ðə seɪm tə mi, ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɔl ə ðiz wɪtnəsəz. pipəl kɔl ɪm ə taɪɹənt, bʌt jə ɑɹ ðə wʌn dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ əɹ lɔz ən ɹulɪŋ baɪ fɪɹ."

"There is often truth in speculation," Egwene said. "You locked the Dragon Reborn himself in a box; you just threatened to do the same to me, in front of all of these witnesses. People call him a tyrant, but you are the one destroying our laws and ruling by fear."

ɪleɪɾəz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, hɝ æŋɡɝ vɪzəbəl. ʃi simd . . . ʃɑkt. əz ɪf ʃi kʊdn ʌndɝstæn haʊ ʃid ɡɔn fɹəm dɪsəplənɪŋ ən ənɹuli nɑvəs ɪndə dəbeɪɾɪŋ ən ikwəl. ɛɡwin sɔ ðə wʊmən bɪɡɪn tə wiv ə θɹɛɾ ʌv ɛɹ. ðət hæd tə bi stɑpt. ə ɡæɡ ʌv ɛɹ wəɾ ɛn ðɪs dəbeɪt.

Elaida's eyes opened wide, her anger visible. She seemed . . . shocked. As if she couldn't understand how she'd gone from disciplining an unruly novice into debating an equal. Egwene saw the woman begin to weave a thread of Air. That had to be stopped. A gag of Air would end this debate.

"ɡoʊ əhɛd," ɛɡwin sɛd kɑmli. "juz ðə paʊɝ tə saɪləns mi. əz æmɪɝlɪn, ʃʊdn jə bi eɪbəl tə tɔk ən əpoʊnən ɪndə oʊbiɾiəns, ɹæðɝ ðən ɹɪzɔɹɾɪŋ tə fɔɹs?"

"Go ahead," Egwene said calmly. "Use the Power to silence me. As Amyrlin, shouldn't you be able to talk an opponent into obedience, rather than resorting to force?"

aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ, ɛɡwin sɔ dɪmɪnjəɾɪv jukɪɝi, ʌv ðə ɡɹeɪ, nɑɾ ət ðət kɑmɛnt.

Out of the corner of her eye, Egwene saw diminutive Yukiri, of the Gray, nod at that comment.

ɪleɪɾəz aɪz flɛɹɾ ɪn æŋɡɝ əz ʃi dʒɹɑp ðə θɹɛɾ ʌv ɛɹ. "aɪ doʊnt nid tə ɹɪbʌɾ ə mɪɹ nɑvəs," ɪleɪɾə snæpt. "ði æmɪɝlɪn dʌzn ɪkspleɪn hɝsɛlf tə wʌn sətʃ əz ju."

Elaida's eyes flared in anger as she dropped the thread of Air. "I don't need to rebut a mere novice," Elaida snapped. "The Amyrlin doesn't explain herself to one such as you."

" 'ði æmɪɝlɪn ʌndɝstænz ðə moʊs kɑmplɛks ə kɹidz ən dəbeɪts,' " ɛɡwin sɛd, kwoʊɾɪŋ fɹəm mɛmɹi. " 'jɛɾ ɪn ði ɛnd, ʃiz ðə sɝvən ʌv ɔl, ivən ðə loʊəst ə leɪbɝɝz.' " ðət hæd bɪn sɛd baɪ bælɑdɑɹ ɝændeɪl, ðə fɝst æmɪɝlɪn tə bi ɹeɪz fɹəm ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ. ʃid juz ðə wɝdz ɪn əɹ læst ɹaɪɾɪŋz bɪfɔɹ əɹ dɛθ; ðoʊz ɹaɪɾɪŋz hæd bɪn ən ɛkspləneɪʃən ə hɝ ɹeɪn ən wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn dʊɹɪŋ ðə kɑvɑɹθən wɔɹz. ɝændeɪl hæd fɛl ðət wʌns ə kɹaɪsəs wɑz pæst, ɪt wɑz ðə mɔɹəl duɾi ʌv ən æmɪɝlɪn tə ɪkspleɪn hɝsɛlf tə ðə kɑmən pipəl.

" 'The Amyrlin understands the most complex of creeds and debates,' " Egwene said, quoting from memory. " 'Yet in the end, she is the servant of all, even the lowest of laborers.' " That had been said by Balladare Arandaille, the first Amyrlin to be raised from the Brown Ajah. She'd used the words in her last writings before her death; those writings had been an explanation of her reign and what she had done during the Kavarthen wars. Arandaille had felt that once a crisis was passed, it was the moral duty of an Amyrlin to explain herself to the common people.

sɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪɾə, ʃɛvən nɑɾəd əpɹiʃieɪɾɪvli. ðə kwoʊt wɑz sʌmwʌɾ əbskjʊɹ; ɛɡwin blɛsɪd sɪuənz kwaɪət tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪzdəm ə ðə fɔɹmɝ æmɪɝlənz. mʌtʃ ʌv wʌt ʃid sɛd hæd kʌm fɹəm ðə sikɹət hɪstɝiz, bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə nʌmbɝ ə nʌɡəts fɹəm wɪmən sətʃ əz bælɑdɑɹ əz wɛl.

Sitting beside Elaida, Shevan nodded appreciatively. The quote was somewhat obscure; Egwene blessed Siuan's quiet training in the wisdom of the former Amyrlins. Much of what she'd said had come from the secret histories, but there had been a number of nuggets from women such as Balladare as well.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs nɑnsɛns jəɹ spʌɾɝɪŋ?" ɪleɪɾə spæt.

"What is this nonsense you're sputtering?" Elaida spat.

"wʌt dɪd jə ɪntɛn tə də wɪð ɹænd ælθɹ wʌns jə kæptʃɝd hɪm?" ɛɡwin sɛd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə kɑmɛnt.

"What did you intend to do with Rand al'Thor once you captured him?" Egwene said, ignoring the comment.

"aɪ doʊnt - "

"I don't - "

"jɔɹ nɑɾ ænsɝɪŋ mi," ɛɡwin sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə teɪbəl ʌv wɪmən, "bʌt ðɛm. hæv jə ɪkspleɪn jɝsɛlf, ɪleɪɾə? wʌt wɝ jəɹ plænz? əɹ wɪl jə dɑdʒ ðɪs kwɛstʃən dʒʌst əz juv ði ʌðɝz aɪv æskt?"

"You're not answering me," Egwene said, nodding to the table of women, "but them. Have you explained yourself, Elaida? What were your plans? Or will you dodge this question just as you have the others I've asked?"

ɪleɪɾəz feɪs wɑz tɝnɪŋ ɹɛd, bʌt ʃi kɑm hɝsɛlf wɪð səm ɛfɝt. "aɪ wʊɾə kɛpt ɪm sɪkjʊɹ, ən wɛl ʃildɪd, hɪɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ əntɪl ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. ðət wʊɾə pɹɪvɛntɪɾ ɪm fɹəm kɑzɪŋ ðə sʌfɝɪŋ ən keɪɑs hiz kɹieɪɾəd ɪn mɛni neɪʃənz. ɪt wɑz wɝθ ðə ɹɪsk ʌv æŋɡɝɪŋ hɪm."

Elaida's face was turning red, but she calmed herself with some effort. "I would have kept him secure, and well shielded, here in the Tower until it was time for the Last Battle. That would have prevented him from causing the suffering and chaos he's created in many nations. It was worth the risk of angering him."

" 'æz ðə plaʊ bɹeɪks ði ɝθ ʃæl i bɹeɪk ðə laɪvz ə mɛn, ən ɔl ðət wɑz ʃæl bi kənsumd ɪn ðə faɪɝ ə hɪz aɪz,' " ɛɡwin sɛd. " 'ðə tʃɹʌmpəts ʌv wɔɹ ʃæl saʊn əɾ ɪz fʊtstɛps, ðə ɹeɪvənz fiɾ əɾ ɪz vɔɪs, ən i ʃæl wɛɹ ə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz.' "

" 'As the plow breaks the earth shall he break the lives of men, and all that was shall be consumed in the fire of his eyes,' " Egwene said. " 'The trumpets of war shall sound at his footsteps, the ravens feed at his voice, and he shall wear a crown of swords.' "

ɪleɪɾə fɹaʊnd, teɪkən əbæk.

Elaida frowned, taken aback.

"ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl, ɪleɪɾə," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wɛn jə hæd ɹænd lɑkt əweɪ tə bi kɛpt 'sɪkjʊɹ,' hæɾ i jɛt teɪkən ɪljən? hæɾ i jɛt wɔɹn wʌɾ i wɑz tə neɪm ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz?"

"The Karaethon Cycle, Elaida," Egwene said. "When you had Rand locked away to be kept 'secure,' had he yet taken Illian? Had he yet worn what he was to name the Crown of Swords?"

"wɛl, noʊ."

"Well, no."

"æn haʊ dɪd jə ɪkspɛkt ɪm tə fʊlfɪl ðə pɹɑfəsiz ɪf i wɑz hɪɾən əweɪ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "haʊ wɑz i tə kɑz wɔɹ, əz ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ hi mʌst? haʊ wɑz i tə bɹeɪk ðə neɪʃənz ən baɪn əm tə hɪm? haʊ kəɾ i 'sleɪ hɪz pipəl wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ə pis' əɹ 'baɪn ðə naɪn munz tə sɝv hɪm' ɪf i wɑz lɑkt əweɪ? də ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ ðət hɪl bi 'ənfɛɾɝd'? də ðeɪ nɑt spik ə ðə 'keɪɑs ə hɪz pæsɪŋ'? haʊ kən ɛniθɪŋ pæs əɾ ɔl ɪf hiz kɛpt ɪn tʃeɪnz?"

"And how did you expect him to fulfill the prophecies if he was hidden away in the White Tower?" Egwene said. "How was he to cause war, as the prophecies say he must? How was he to break the nations and bind them to him? How could he 'slay his people with the sword of peace' or 'bind the nine moons to serve him' if he was locked away? Do the prophecies say that he will be 'unfettered'? Do they not speak of the 'chaos of his passing'? How can anything pass at all if he is kept in chains?"

"aɪ. . . ."

"I. . . ."

"jɔɹ lɑdʒɪk ɪz əstaʊndɪŋ, ɪleɪɾə," ɛɡwin sɛd koʊldli. ət ðæt, fɛɹən smaɪl slaɪli; ʃi wɑz pɹɑbli θɪŋkɪŋ jɛɾ əɡɛn ðəɾ ɛɡwin wəd fɪt wɛl ɪn ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ.

"Your logic is astounding, Elaida," Egwene said coldly. At that, Ferane smiled slyly; she was probably thinking yet again that Egwene would fit well in the White Ajah.

"bɑ," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, "ju æsk minɪŋləs kwɛstʃənz. ðə pɹɑfəsiz wəɾ əv tə hæv bɪn fʊlfɪld. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ."

"Bah," Elaida said, "you ask meaningless questions. The prophecies would have to have been fulfilled. There was no other way."

"soʊ jəɹ seɪɪŋ ðət jəɹ ətɛmp tə baɪn ɪm wɑz dɛstɪn tə feɪl."

"So you're saying that your attempt to bind him was destined to fail."

"noʊ, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, ɹɛd-feɪst əɡɛn. "wi ʃʊdn bi bɑðɝɪŋ wɪð ðɪs - ɪts nɑt fəɹ jə tə dɪsaɪɾ əpɑn. noʊ, wi ʃəd bi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt jəɹ ɹɛbəlz, ən wʌt ðeɪv dʌn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ!"

"No, not at all," Elaida said, red-faced again. "We shouldn't be bothering with this - it's not for you to decide upon. No, we should be talking about your rebels, and what they've done to the White Tower!"

ə ɡʊd tɝn ə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən, ən ətɛmp tə pʊɾ ɛɡwin ɑn ðə dɪfɛnsɪv. ɪleɪɾə wɑzn kəmplitli ɪnkɑmpəɾənt. dʒʌst ɛɹəɡənt.

A good turn of the conversation, an attempt to put Egwene on the defensive. Elaida wasn't completely incompetent. Just arrogant.

"aɪ si ðɛm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hil ðə ɹɪf bɪtwin ʌs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wi kænɑt tʃeɪnʒ wʌɾ əz hæpənd. wi kæn tʃeɪnʒ wʌt jə dɪd tə sɪuən, ivən ɪf ðoʊz wɪð mi dɪd dɪskʌvɝ ə mɛθəɾ ə hilɪŋ əɹ stɪlɪŋ. wi kən oʊnli muv fɔɹwɝɾ ən tʃɹaɪ əɹ bɛs tə smuð ðə skɑɹz. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ, ɪleɪɾə? ɹəfjuzɪŋ tɔks, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bʊli ðə sɪɾɝz ɪndə wɪθdʒɹɔɪŋ? ɪnsʌltɪŋ ədʒəz ðəɾ ɑɹ nɑt jəɹ oʊn?"

"I see them trying to heal the rift between us," Egwene said. "We cannot change what has happened. We can't change what you did to Siuan, even if those with me did discover a method of Healing her stilling. We can only move forward and try our best to smooth the scars. What are you doing, Elaida? Refusing talks, trying to bully the Sitters into withdrawing? Insulting Ajahs that are not your own?"

dʌsin, ʌv ðə jɛloʊ, ɡeɪv ə kwaɪət mɝmɝ ʌv əɡɹimənt. ðət dʒɹu ɪleɪɾəz aɪz, ən ʃi fɛl saɪlən fəɹ ə moʊmənt, əz ɪf ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə dəbeɪt. "ɪnʌf ə ðɪs."

Doesine, of the Yellow, gave a quiet murmur of agreement. That drew Elaida's eyes, and she fell silent for a moment, as if realizing that she had lost control of the debate. "Enough of this."

"kaʊɝd," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Coward," Egwene said.

ɪleɪɾəz aɪz flɛɹd waɪd. "haʊ dɛɹ ju!"

Elaida's eyes flared wide. "How dare you!"

"aɪ dɛɹ ðə tʃɹuθ, ɪleɪɾə," ɛɡwin sɛd kwaɪətli. "ju ɑɹ ə kaʊɝɾ ən ə taɪɹənt. aɪd neɪm jə dɑɹkfɹɛn əz wɛl, bʌɾ aɪ səspɛk ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn wəd pɝhæps bi ɪmbɛɹəs tə əsoʊsieɪt wɪð ju."

"I dare the truth, Elaida," Egwene said quietly. "You are a coward and a tyrant. I'd name you Darkfriend as well, but I suspect that the Dark One would perhaps be embarrassed to associate with you."

ɪleɪɾə skɹitʃt, wivɪŋ ɪn ə flæʃ ə paʊɝ, slæmɪŋ ɛɡwin bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, tɑpəlɪŋ ðə pɪtʃɝ ʌv waɪn fɹəm əɹ hænz. ɪt ʃæɾɝd ɑn ə pætʃ ʌv wʊɾən flɔɹ bɪsaɪd ðə ɹʌɡ, θɹoʊɪŋ ə spɹeɪ ʌv blʌdlaɪk lɪkwəɾ əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl ən hæf ʌv ɪts ɑkjəpəns, steɪnɪŋ ðə waɪt teɪbəlklɔθ wɪð ə smɪɹ ə ɹɛd.

Elaida screeched, weaving in a flash of Power, slamming Egwene back against the wall, toppling the pitcher of wine from her hands. It shattered on a patch of wooden floor beside the rug, throwing a spray of bloodlike liquid across the table and half of its occupants, staining the white tablecloth with a smear of red.

"ju neɪm mi dɑɹkfɹɛnd?" ɪleɪɾə skɹimd. "ju ɑɹ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. jə ən ðoʊz ɹɛbəlz aʊtsaɪd, hu sik tə dɪstʃɹæk mi fɹəm duɪŋ wʌt mʌs bi dʌn."

"You name me Darkfriend?" Elaida screamed. "You are the Darkfriend. You and those rebels outside, who seek to distract me from doing what must be done."

ə blæst ʌv woʊvən ɛɹ slæmd ɛɡwin əɡɛns ðə wɔl əɡɛn, ən ʃi dʒɹɑp tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, hɪɾɪŋ ʃɑɹdz ə ðə bɹoʊkən pɪtʃɝ ðət slaɪst oʊpən əɹ ɑɹmz. ə dʌzən swɪtʃəz bit hɝ, ɹɪpɪŋ əɹ kloʊðɪŋ. blʌd sip fɹəm əɹ ɑɹmz, ən ɪt bɪɡæn tə splæʃ ɪndə ði ɛɹ, smɝtʃɪŋ ðə wɔl əz ɪleɪɾə bit hɝ.

A blast of woven Air slammed Egwene against the wall again, and she dropped to the ground, hitting shards of the broken pitcher that sliced open her arms. A dozen switches beat her, ripping her clothing. Blood seeped from her arms, and it began to splash into the air, smirching the wall as Elaida beat her.

"ɪleɪɾə, stɑp ɪt!" ɹubɪn sɛd, stændɪŋ, ɡɹin dʒɹɛs swɪʃɪŋ. "ɑɹ jə mæd?"

"Elaida, stop it!" Rubinde said, standing, green dress swishing. "Are you mad?"

ɪleɪɾə tɝnd, pæntɪŋ. "du nɑt tɛmp mi, ɡɹin!"

Elaida turned, panting. "Do not tempt me, Green!"

ðə swɪtʃəz kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə biɾ ɛɡwin. ʃi bɔɹ ɪt saɪlənli. wɪð ɛfɝt, ʃi stʊɾ ʌp. ʃi kəd fil əɹ feɪs ən ɑɹmz swɛlɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi. bʌt ʃi meɪnteɪn ə kɑm ɡeɪz əɾ ɪleɪɾə.

The switches continuing to beat Egwene. She bore it silently. With effort, she stood up. She could feel her face and arms swelling already. But she maintained a calm gaze at Elaida.

"ɪleɪɾə!" fɛɹən jɛld, stændɪŋ. "ju vaɪəleɪt taʊɝ lɔ! jə kænɑt juz ðə paʊɝ tə pʌnɪʃ ən ɪnɪʃiət!"

"Elaida!" Ferane yelled, standing. "You violate Tower law! You cannot use the Power to punish an initiate!"

" aɪm taʊɝ lɔ!" ɪleɪɾə ɹeɪvd. ʃi pɔɪntəɾ ət ðə sɪstɝz. "ju mɑk mi. aɪ noʊ jə də ɪt.

" I am Tower law!" Elaida raved. She pointed at the sisters. "You mock me. I know you do it.

bɪhaɪn maɪ bæk. jə ʃoʊ mi dɛfɝəns wən jə si mi, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ wʌt jə seɪ, wʌt jə wɪspɝ. jə ənɡɹeɪtfəl fulz! æftɝ wʌɾ aɪv dʌn fəɹ ju! dʒju θɪŋk əl sʌfɝ jə fɝɛvɝ?

Behind my back. You show me deference when you see me, but I know what you say, what you whisper. You ungrateful fools! After what I've done for you! Do you think I'll suffer you forever?

teɪk ðɪs wʌn əz ən ɪɡzæmpəl!"

Take this one as an example!"

ʃi spʌn, pɔɪntɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin, ðən stʌmbəl bæk ɪn ʃɑk tə faɪn ɛɡwin kɑmli wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ.

She spun, pointing at Egwene, then stumbled back in shock to find Egwene calmly watching her.

ɪleɪɾə ɡæsp sɔfli, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə hɝ bɹɛst əz ðə swɪtʃəz bit. ðeɪ kəɾ ɔl si ðə wivz, ən ðeɪ kəɾ ɔl si ðəɾ ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt skɹim, ɔlðoʊ hɝ maʊθ wɑz nɑt ɡæɡd wɪð ɛɹ. hɝ ɑɹmz dʒɹɪp blʌd, hɝ bɑɾi wɑz biɾən bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ən jɛt ʃi faʊnd noʊ ɹizən tə skɹim.

Elaida gasped softly, raising a hand to her breast as the switches beat. They could all see the weaves, and they could all see that Egwene did not scream, although her mouth was not gagged with Air. Her arms dripped blood, her body was beaten before them, and yet she found no reason to scream.

ɪnstɛd, ʃi kwaɪətli blɛs ði il waɪz wʌnz fəɹ ðɛɹ wɪzdəm.

Instead, she quietly blessed the Aiel Wise Ones for their wisdom.

"ænd wʌt," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ivənli, "æm aɪ tə bi ən ɪɡzæmpəl ʌv, ɪleɪɾə?"

"And what," Egwene said evenly, "am I to be an example of, Elaida?"

ðə biɾɪŋ kəntɪnjud. oʊ, haʊ ɪt hɝt! tɪɹz fɔɹmd ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝz ʌv ɛɡwinz aɪz, bʌt ʃi hæd fɛlt wɝs. fɑɹ wɝs. ʃi fɛlt ɪɾ itʃ taɪm ʃi θɔɾ ʌv wʌt ðɪs wʊmən wɑz duɪŋ tə ði ɪnstɪtuʃən ʃi lʌvd. hɝ tʃɹu peɪn wɑz nɑt fɹəm ðə wunz, bʌt fɹəm haʊ ɪleɪɾə hæɾ æktəd bɪfɔɹ ðə sɪɾɝz.

The beating continued. Oh, how it hurt! Tears formed in the corners of Egwene's eyes, but she had felt worse. Far worse. She felt it each time she thought of what this woman was doing to the institution she loved. Her true pain was not from the wounds, but from how Elaida had acted before the Sitters.

"baɪ ðə laɪt," ɹubɪnd wɪspɝd.

"By the Light," Rubinde whispered.

"aɪ wɪʃ aɪ wɝnt niɾəd hɪɹ, ɪleɪɾə," ɛɡwin sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ wɪʃ ðət ðə taʊɝ hæɾ ə ɡɹæn æmɪɝlɪn ɪn ju. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd stɛp daʊn ən æksɛp jəɹ ɹul. aɪ wɪʃ jə dɪzɝvd ɪt. aɪ wəd wɪlɪŋli æksɛpt ɛksəkjuʃən, ɪf ɪt wəd min livɪŋ ə kɑmpəɾənt æmɪɝlɪn. ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən aɪ æm. kən jə seɪ ðə seɪm?"

"I wish I weren't needed here, Elaida," Egwene said softly. "I wish that the Tower had a grand Amyrlin in you. I wish I could step down and accept your rule. I wish you deserved it. I would willingly accept execution, if it would mean leaving a competent Amyrlin. The White Tower is more important than I am. Can you say the same?"

"ju wɑn ɛksəkjuʃən!" ɪleɪɾə bɛloʊd, ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ əɹ tʌŋ. "wɛl, jə ʃæl nɑɾ əv ɪt!

"You want execution!" Elaida bellowed, recovering her tongue. "Well, you shall not have it!

dɛθ ɪz tu ɡʊd fəɹ ju, dɑɹkfɹɛnd! aɪ ʃæl si jə biɾən - ɛvɹiwʌn ʃæl si jə biɾən - əntɪl aɪm θɹu wɪð ju. oʊnli ðən wɪl jə daɪ!" ʃi tɝn tə ðə sɝvəns, hu stʊd, ɡeɪpɪŋ, ət ðə saɪdz ə ðə ɹum. Death is too good for you, Darkfriend! I shall see you beaten - everyone shall see you beaten - until I am through with you. Only then will you die!" She turned to the servants, who stood, gaping, at the sides of the room. "Send for soldiers! I want this one cast into the deepest cell this Tower can provide! sɝvəns ɹæn tə də əz ʃi dɪmændəd. ðə swɪtʃəz kəntɪnjud tə bit, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ nʌm. ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, filɪŋ feɪnt - ʃi hæd lɔs mʌtʃ blʌd fɹəm əɹ lɛft ɑɹm, wɪtʃ bɔɹ ðə dipəst ə hɝ ɡæʃəz.

Servants ran to do as she demanded. The switches continued to beat, but Egwene was growing numb. She closed her eyes, feeling faint - she had lost much blood from her left arm, which bore the deepest of her gashes.

ɪt hæd kʌm tə ə hɛd, əz ʃid fɪɹd ðəɾ ɪt wʊd. ʃi hæd kæst əɹ lɑt.

It had come to a head, as she'd feared that it would. She had cast her lot.

bʌt ʃi dɪdn fɪɹ fəɹ əɹ laɪf. ɪnstɛd, ʃi fɪɹd fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. əz ʃi lin bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, θɔts feɪɾɪŋ, ʃi wɑz oʊvɝkʌm wɪð sɑɹoʊ.

But she didn't fear for her life. Instead, she feared for the White Tower. As she leaned back against the wall, thoughts fading, she was overcome with sorrow.

hɝ bæɾəl fɹəm wɪðɪn ðə taʊɝ wɑz əɾ ən ɛnd, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ.

Her battle from within the Tower was at an end, one way or another.

Questions of Control "You should be more careful," Sarene said from inside the room. "The Amyrlin Seat, we have much influence with her. Your punishments, we may be able to persuade her to lessen them, if you are helpful."

Semirhage's sniff of disdain was quite audible to Cadsuane, listening from the hallway outside the interrogation room, sitting in a comfortable log chair. Cadsuane sipped at a cup of warm sweetleaf.

ðə hɔlweɪ wɑz ə sɪmpəl wʊd, kɑɹpəɾɪd wɪð ə lɔŋ mɝun ən waɪt ɹʌɡ, pɹɪzmlaɪk læmps ɑn ðə wɔlz flɪkɝɪŋ wɪð laɪt.

The hallway was of simple wood, carpeted with a long maroon and white rug, prismlike lamps on the walls flickering with light.

There were several others in the hallway with her - Daigian, Erian, Elza - whose turn it was to maintain Semirhage's shield. Aside from Cadsuane, each Aes Sedai in the camp took turns. It was too dangerous to risk forcing the duty only on the Aes Sedai of lesser stature, lest they grow weary. The shield had to remain strong. Light only knew what would happen if Semirhage got free.

Cadsuane sipped her tea, her back to the wall. Al'Thor had insisted that "his" Aes Sedai be allowed opportunities to interrogate Semirhage, instead of just those Cadsuane had chosen. She wasn't certain if this was some attempt at asserting his authority or if he genuinely thought that they might succeed where she - so far - had failed.

Sarene also didn't know that Cadsuane was outside eavesdropping, through the use of a weave of Air and Fire. It was a simple trick, one often learned by novices. Mixing it with this newly found trick of inverting one's weaves meant that Cadsuane could listen in without anyone inside knowing that she was there.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊtsaɪd sɔ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt nʌn sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ. ivən ðoʊ tu ʌv əm - ɛlzə ən ɛɹiən - wɝ əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹup ə fulz u hæd swɔɹn fiəlti tə ði ælθɹ bɔɪ, ðeɪ stɛp laɪtli ɝaʊn hɝ; ðeɪ nu haʊ ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðɛm. ɪɾiət wɪmən. ət taɪmz, ɪt sim ðət hæf ə hɝ ælaɪz wɝ oʊnli dɪtɝmən tə meɪk əɹ dʒɑb hɑɹɾɝ.

jəl bɹɪŋ mi sʌmθɪŋ əpɹoʊpɹiət."

sɝin kəntɪnjud, "ðɪs nɛks kwɛstʃən, ɪɾəl dətɝmən ɪf jə æktʃəli  ɡɛt tə it ðət mil əɹ nɑt."

dɪspaɪt ðə fɝm vɔɪs, kædzueɪn kəd hɪɹ ə kwɪknəs tə sɝinz wɝdz. ðə sʌɾən dʒɹɑp ə ðə tʃɹeɪ ʌv fud hæd stɑɹɾəld hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl soʊ dʒʌmpi ɝaʊn ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ðeɪ wɝn dɛfɝɛntʃəl, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd tʃɹit sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɪð ə mɛʒɝ ə ɹɪspɛkt. haʊ kəd ðeɪ nɑt? ʃi wɑz ə lɛdʒənd. wʌn dɪd nɑɾ ɛntɝ ðə pɹɛzəns ə sətʃ ə kɹitʃɝ - wʌn ə ðə moʊst ivəl biɪŋz ɛvɝ tə lɪv - ən nɑt fil ət list ə mɛʒɝ ʌv ɑ.

Despite the firm voice, Cadsuane could hear a quickness to Sarene's words. The sudden drop of the tray of food had startled her. They were all so jumpy around the Forsaken. They weren't deferential, but they did treat Semirhage with a measure of respect. How could they not? She was a legend. One did not enter the presence of such a creature - one of the most evil beings ever to live - and not feel at least a measure of awe.

mɛʒɝ ʌv ɑ. . . .

Measure of awe. . . .

"ðæts əɹ mɪsteɪk," kædzueɪn wɪspɝd. ʃi blɪŋkt, ðən tɝn ən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ɪndə ðə ɹum.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ stʊɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə smɔl tʃeɪmbɝ. ʃi hæd bɪn ɹɛtaɪɾ ɪn ɛɹ, ðə wivz laɪkli woʊvən ðə moʊmən ðət ʃid dʒɹɑpt əɹ tʃɹeɪ. ðə bɹæs plæɾɝ leɪ dɪskɑɹɾɪd, ðə binz soʊkɪŋ dʒus ɪndə ði eɪdʒɪd wʊɾən bɔɹdz. ðɪs ɹum hæd noʊ wɪndoʊ; ɪt hæd bɪn ə stɔɹədʒ tʃeɪmbɝ ət wʌn pɔɪnt, kənvɝɾɪd ɪndə ə "sɛl" tə hoʊl ðə fɔɹseɪkən. sɝin - dɑɹk hɛɹ ɪn biɾɪd bɹeɪdz, bjuɾəfəl feɪs sɝpɹaɪzd ət ði ɪntʃɹuʒən - sæɾ ɪn ə tʃɛɹ bɪfɔɹ sɛmɝhɪdʒ. hɝ wɔɹɾɝ, vaɪɾəliən, bɹɔd- ʃoʊldɝɾ ən æʃən-feɪst, stʊɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ.

Semirhage stood in the center of the small chamber. She had been retied in Air, the weaves likely woven the moment that she'd dropped her tray. The brass platter lay discarded, the beans soaking juice into the aged wooden boards. This room had no window; it had been a storage chamber at one point, converted into a "cell" to hold the Forsaken. Sarene - dark hair in beaded braids, beautiful face surprised at the intrusion - sat in a chair before Semirhage. Her Warder, Vitalien, broad- shouldered and ashen-faced, stood in the corner.

sɛmɝhɪdʒəz hɛd wɑz nɑt baʊnd, ən əɹ aɪz flɪk təwɔɹd kædzueɪn.

Semirhage's head was not bound, and her eyes flicked toward Cadsuane.

kædzueɪn hæd kəmɪɾəd hɝsɛlf; ʃi hæd tə kənfɹʌn ðə wʊmən naʊ. fɔɹtʃənətli, wʌt ʃi plæn dɪdn ɹikwaɪɝ mʌtʃ dɛləkəsi. ɪɾ ɔl keɪm bæk tə ə sɪŋɡəl kwɛstʃən. haʊ wəd kædzueɪn bɹeɪk hɝsɛlf? ðə səluʃən wɑz izi, naʊ ðəɾ ɪɾ əkɝd tə hɝ.

Cadsuane had committed herself; she had to confront the woman now. Fortunately, what she planned didn't require much delicacy. It all came back to a single question. How would Cadsuane break herself? The solution was easy, now that it occurred to her.

"ɑ," kædzueɪn sɛd wɪð ə noʊ-nɑnsɛns æɾətud. "aɪ si ðət ðə tʃaɪld əz ɹəfjuzd əɹ mil.

sɝin, ɹilis jəɹ wivz."

Sarene, release your weaves."

Semirhage raised her eyebrows and opened her mouth to scoff, but as Sarene released her weaves of Air, Cadsuane grabbed Semirhage by the hair and - with a casual sweep of her foot - knocked the woman's legs out from beneath her, dropping her to the floor.

pɝhæps ʃi cʊɾə juz ðə paʊɝ, bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ɹaɪt tə juz əɹ hænz fəɹ ðɪs. ʃi pɹipɛɹɾ ə fju wivz, ðoʊ ʃi pɹɑbli wʊdnt nid ðɛm. sɛmɝhɪdʒ, ðoʊ tɔl, wɑz ə wʊmən ʌv wɪləwi bɪld, ən kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn mɔɹ staʊt ðən ʃi wɑz slɪm. plʌs, ðə fɔɹseɪkən simd ʌɾɝli dʌmfaʊndɪɾ ət haʊ ʃi wɑz biɪŋ tʃɹiɾəd.

Perhaps she could have used the Power, but it felt right to use her hands for this. She prepared a few weaves, though she probably wouldn't need them. Semirhage, though tall, was a woman of willowy build, and Cadsuane herself had always been more stout than she was slim. Plus, the Forsaken seemed utterly dumbfounded at how she was being treated.

kædzueɪn nɛl daʊn wɪð wʌn ni ɑn ðə wʊmənz bæk, ðən ʃʌvd əɹ feɪs fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə ðə spɪl fud. "it," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ doʊn əpɹuv ʌv weɪstəd fud, tʃaɪld, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli dʊɹɪŋ ðiz taɪmz."

Cadsuane knelt down with one knee on the woman's back, then shoved her face forward into the spilled food. "Eat," she said. "I don't approve of wasted food, child, particularly during these times."

Semirhage sputtered, releasing a few phrases that Cadsuane could only assume were oaths, though she didn't recognize any of them. The meanings were likely lost in time. Soon, the oaths subsided and Semirhage grew still. She didn't fight back. Cadsuane wouldn't have either; that would only hurt her image. Semirhage's power as a captive came from the fear and respect that the Aes Sedai gave her.

kædzueɪn niɾəd tə tʃeɪnʒ ðæt.

Cadsuane needed to change that.

The White stood, looking shocked. They had tried all measure of torture available to them under al'Thor's requirements, but each of those had betrayed esteem. They were treating Semirhage as a dangerous force and a worthy enemy. That would only bolster her ego.

sɝin nɑɾəd, ɹʌʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹum. kædzueɪn sæɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ, ðən woʊv θɹɛdz ʌv ɛɹ ən pɪk sɛmɝhɪdʒ ʌp. ɛlzə ən ɛɹiən ɡlænst ɪndə ðə ɹum, lʊkɪŋ vɛɹi kjʊɹiəs. ðən ðeɪ ɛntɝd, sɝin fɑloʊɪŋ. ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ, deɪdʒiən ɛntɝd wɪð faɪv sɝvəns: θɹi dəmɑni wɪmən ɪn eɪpɹənz, wʌn spɪnli mæn, hɪz fɪŋɡɝz bɹaʊn wɪð steɪn fɹəm ɹɛkoʊɾɪŋ lɔɡz, ən ə sɪŋɡəl sɝvɪŋ bɔɪ.

Sarene nodded, rushing from the room. Cadsuane sat in the chair, then wove threads of Air and picked Semirhage up. Elza and Erian glanced into the room, looking very curious. Then they entered, Sarene following. A few moments later, Daigian entered with five servants: three Domani women in aprons, one spindly man, his fingers brown with stain from recoating logs, and a single serving boy.

ɛksələnt.

Excellent.

əz ðeɪ ɛntɝd, kædzueɪn juzd əɹ θɹɛdz ʌv ɛɹ tə tɝn sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɝaʊn əkɹɔs əɹ ni. ən ðən ʃi pɹəsiɾəd tə spæŋk ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ hɛld aʊɾ ət fɝst. ðən ʃi bɪɡæn tə kɝs. ðən ʃi bɪɡæn tə spʌɾɝ aʊt θɹɛts.

kædzueɪn kəntɪnjud, hɝ hæn bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə hɝt. sɛmɝhɪdʒəz θɹɛts tɝn tə haʊlz ʌv aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ ən peɪn. ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl wɪð ðə fud ɹɪtɝn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt, æɾɪŋ ivən mɔɹ tə sɛmɝhɪdʒəz ʃeɪm. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑtʃt wɪð slæk dʒɔz.

Cadsuane "tsk"ed and began again. The crowd in the room watched in amazed silence. Semirhage began to cry - not from the pain, but from the humiliation. That was the key. Semirhage could not be defeated by pain or by persuasion - but destroying her image, that would be more terrible in her mind than any other punishment. Just as it would have been for Cadsuane.

kædzueɪn stɪld əɹ hæn æftɝ ə fju mɔɹ mɪnəts, ɹilisɪŋ ðə wivz ðət hɛl sɛmɝhɪdʒ moʊʃənləs. "wɪl jə it?" ʃi æskt.
