Now, Cadsuane thought, leaving the room, what to do about al'Thor?

"maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz wɛðɝd feɪs, "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə ʌndɝstænd."

"My Lord," Grady said, rubbing his weathered face, "I don't think you understand."

"ðɛn ɪkspleɪn ɪt tə mi," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hi stʊɾ ɑn ə hɪlsaɪd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn oʊvɝ ðə hjudʒ ɡæðɝɪŋ ə ɹɛfjudʒiz ən soʊlʒɝz. mɪsmætʃt tɛns ə mɛni dɪfɹən dɪzaɪnz - tæn, sɪŋɡəl-pikt il stʃɹʌktʃɝz; kʌlɝfəl lɑɹdʒ kɛɹhinɪn wʌnz; tu-tɪp tɛns ə beɪsɪk dɪzaɪn - spɹæŋ ʌp əz ðə pipəl pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ðə naɪt.

"Then explain it to me," Perrin said. He stood on a hillside, looking down over the huge gathering of refugees and soldiers. Mismatched tents of many different designs - tan, single-peaked Aiel structures; colorful large Cairhienin ones; two-tipped tents of basic design - sprang up as the people prepared for the night.

ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ il, əz hoʊpt, hæd nɑt ɡɪvən tʃeɪs. ðeɪ hæd lɛt pɛɹɪnz ɑɹmi wɪðdʒɹɔ, ðoʊ hɪz skaʊts sɛd ðət ðeɪ hæd naʊ muvd ɪn tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt ðə sɪɾi. iðɝ weɪ, ɪt mɛn pɛɹɪn hæd taɪm.

The Shaido Aiel, as hoped, had not given chase. They had let Perrin's army withdraw, though his scouts said that they had now moved in to investigate the city. Either way, it meant Perrin had time.

taɪm tə ɹɛst, taɪm tə lɪmp əweɪ, taɪm - hid hoʊpt - tə juz ɡeɪtweɪz tə tʃɹænspɔɹɾ əweɪ moʊst ə ðiz ɹɛfjudʒiz.

Time to rest, time to limp away, time - he'd hoped - to use gateways to transport away most of these refugees.

laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡ ɡɹup. θaʊzənz əpɑn θaʊzənz ə pipəl, ə naɪtmɛɹ tə koʊɔɹɾəneɪt ən ədmɪnəstɝ tə. hɪz læs fju deɪz hæd bɪn fɪld wɪð ən ɛnləs stʃɹim ə kəmpleɪns, əbdʒɛkʃənz, dʒʌdʒməns ən peɪpɝz. wɛɹ dɪd beɪlwɝ faɪn soʊ mʌtʃ peɪpɝ? ɪt sim tə sæɾəsfaɪ mɛni ʌv ðə pipəl u keɪm tə pɛɹɪn. dʒʌdʒməns ən ðə sɛɾəlmənt ə dɪspjuts sim soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ əfɪʃəl tə ðɛm wən ə pis ə peɪpɝ aʊtlaɪn ðɛm. beɪlwɝ sɛd pɛɹɪn wəd niɾ ə sil.

Light, but it was a big group. Thousands upon thousands of people, a nightmare to coordinate and administer to. His last few days had been filled with an endless stream of complaints, objections, judgments and papers. Where did Balwer find so much paper? It seemed to satisfy many of the people who came to Perrin. Judgments and the settlement of disputes seemed so much more official to them when a piece of paper outlined them. Balwer said Perrin would need a seal.

ðə wɝk hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ, wɪtʃ wɑz ɡʊd. bʌt pɛɹɪn nu hi kʊdn pʊʃ əsaɪɾ ɪz pɹɑbləmz fəɹ lɔŋ. ɹænd pʊld ɪm nɔɹθwɝd. pɛɹɪn hæd tə mɑɹtʃ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. nʌθɪŋ ɛls mæɾɝd.

The work had been distracting, which was good. But Perrin knew he couldn't push aside his problems for long. Rand pulled him northward. Perrin had to march for the Last Battle. Nothing else mattered.

ən jɛt, ðət vɛɹi sɪŋɡəl-maɪndɪdnəs ɪn ɪm - ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ bʌɾ ɪz əbdʒɛktɪv - hæd bɪn ðə sɔɹs ə mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl dʊɹɪŋ ɪz hʌn fəɹ feɪl. hi hæd tə faɪn ə bæləns, sʌmhaʊ. hi niɾəd tə dɪsaɪd fəɹ hɪmsɛlf ɪf i wɑntəd tə lid ðiz pipəl. hi niɾəd tə meɪk pis wɪð ðə wʊlf ɪnsaɪd hɪmsɛlf, ðə bis ðət ɹeɪdʒd wən i wɛn ɪndə bæɾəl.

And yet, that very single-mindedness in him - ignoring everything but his objective - had been the source of much trouble during his hunt for Faile. He had to find a balance, somehow. He needed to decide for himself if he wanted to lead these people. He needed to make peace with the wolf inside himself, the beast that raged when he went into battle.

bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəd də ɛni ʌv ðæt, hi niɾəd tə ɡɛt ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz hoʊm. ðət wɑz pɹuvɪŋ ə pɹɑbləm. "juv hæd taɪm tə ɹɛs naʊ, ɡɹeɪɾi," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

But before he could do any of that, he needed to get the refugees home. That was proving a problem. "You've had time to rest now, Grady," Perrin said.

"ðə fətiɡ ɪz oʊnli wʌn pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd. "ðoʊ, ɑnəsli, aɪ stɪl fil əz ɪf aɪ kəd slip ə wiks taɪm."

"The fatigue is only one part of it, my Lord," Grady said. "Though, honestly, I still feel as if I could sleep a week's time."

hi dɪd lʊk taɪɝd. ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz ə stɔlwɝt mæn, wɪð ðə feɪs ʌv ə fɑɹmɝ ən ðə tɛmpɹəmən ʌv wʌn, tu. pɛɹɪn wəd tʃɹʌs ðɪs mæn tə də hɪz duɾi bɪfɔɹ moʊs lɔɹdz hid noʊn. bʌt ɡɹeɪɾi kəd bi pʊʃt oʊnli soʊ fɑɹ. wʌɾ ɪt də tə ə mæn, tə hæv tə tʃænəl soʊ mʌtʃ? ɡɹeɪɾi hæd bæɡz bɪniθ ɪz aɪz, ən ɪz feɪs wɑz peɪl dɪspaɪɾ ɪz tæn skɪn. ðoʊ hi wɑz stɪl ə jʌŋ mæn, hid stɑɹɾəd tə ɡoʊ ɡɹeɪ.

He did look tired. Grady was a stalwart man, with the face of a farmer and the temperament of one, too. Perrin would trust this man to do his duty before most lords he'd known. But Grady could be pushed only so far. What did it do to a man, to have to channel so much? Grady had bags beneath his eyes, and his face was pale despite his tanned skin. Though he was still a young man, he'd started to go gray.

laɪt, bʌɾ aɪ juz ðɪs mæn tu hɑɹd, pɛɹɪn θɔt. hɪm ən nil boʊθ. ðət hæd bɪn ənʌðɝ ɪfɛkt ə pɛɹɪnz sɪŋɡəl-maɪndɪdnəs, əz i wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə si. wʌt hid dʌn tə ɛɹæm, haʊ hiɾ əlaʊd ðoʊz ɝaʊn ɪm tə ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt liɾɝʃɪp. . . . aɪ hæv tə fɪks ðɪs. aɪ hæv tə faɪn ə weɪ tə dil wɪð ɪɾ ɔl.

Light, but I used this man too hard, Perrin thought. Him and Neald both. That had been another effect of Perrin's single-mindedness, as he was beginning to see. What he'd done to Aram, how he'd allowed those around him to go without leadership. . . . I have to fix this. I have to find a way to deal with it all.

ɪf i dɪdnt, hi maɪt nɑt ɡɛt tə ðə læs bæɾəl.

If he didn't, he might not get to the Last Battle.

"hɪɹz ðə θɪŋ, maɪ lɔɹd." ɡɹeɪɾi ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn əɡɛn, sɝveɪɪŋ ðə kæmp. ðə vɛɹiəs kəntɪnʒənts - minɝz, æliændɝz ɡɑɹd, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, ði il, ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz fɹəm vɛɹiəs sɪɾiz - ɔl kæmp sɛpɝətli, ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn ɹɪŋz. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ səm hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən pipəl u nid tə ɡɛt hoʊm. ðə wʌnz ðət wɪl liv, ɛniweɪ. mɛni seɪ ðeɪ fil seɪfɝ hɪɹ, wɪð ju."

"Here's the thing, my Lord." Grady rubbed his chin again, surveying the camp. The various contingents - Mayeners, Alliandre's guard, the Two Rivers men, the Aiel, the refugees from various cities - all camped separately, in their own rings. "There are some hundred thousand people who need to get home. The ones that will leave, anyway. Many say they feel safer here, with you."

"ðeɪ kən ɡɪv oʊvɝ wɑntɪŋ ðæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ wɪð ðɛɹ fæmliz."

"They can give over wanting that," Perrin said. "They belong with their families."

"æn ðə wʌnz huz fæmliz ɑɹ ɪn sintʃæn lænz?" ɡɹeɪɾi ʃɹʌɡd. "bɪfɔɹ ði ɪnveɪɾɝz keɪm, mɛni ʌv ðiz pipəl wəd bi hæpi tə ɹɪtɝn. bʌt naʊ . . . wɛl, ðeɪ kip tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt steɪɪŋ wɛɹ ðɛɹz fuɾ ən pɹətɛkʃən."

"And the ones whose families are in Seanchan lands?" Grady shrugged. "Before the invaders came, many of these people would be happy to return. But now . . . Well, they keep talking about staying where there's food and protection."

"wi kən stɪl sɛn ðə wʌnz u wɑnə ɡoʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wil tʃɹævəl laɪɾɝ wɪθaʊt ðɛm."

"We can still send the ones who want to go," Perrin said. "We'll travel lighter without them."

ɡɹeɪɾi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðæts ðə θɪŋ, maɪ lɔɹd. jəɹ mæn, beɪlwɝ, hi ɡeɪv əs ə kaʊnt. aɪ kən meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ əbaʊt tu mɛn tə wɔk θɹu ət wʌns. ɪf jə fɪɡjɝ əm teɪkɪŋ wʌn sɛkən tə ɡoʊ θɹu . . . wɛl, ɪt wəd teɪk aʊɝz ən aʊɝz tə sɛn əm ɔl. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðə nʌmbɝ, bʌɾ i kleɪmd ɪt wəd bi deɪz' wɝθ ʌv wɝk. ən i sɛd ðəɾ ɪz ɛstəməts wɝ pɹɑbli tu ɑptəmɪstɪk. maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ kəd bɛɹli kip ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən ən aʊɝ, wɪð haʊ taɪɝɾ aɪ æm."

Grady shook his head. "That's the thing, my Lord. Your man, Balwer, he gave us a count. I can make a gateway big enough for about two men to walk through at once. If you figure them taking one second to go through . . . Well, it would take hours and hours to send them all. I don't know the number, but he claimed it would be days' worth of work. And he said that his estimates were probably too optimistic. My Lord, I could barely keep a gateway open an hour, with how tired I am."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. hiɾ əv tə ɡɛt ðoʊz nʌmbɝz fɹəm beɪlwɝ hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ i hæɾ ə sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ ðət beɪlwɝ wəd bi ɹaɪt.

Perrin gritted his teeth. He'd have to get those numbers from Balwer himself, but he had a sinking feeling that Balwer would be right.

"wil kip mɑɹtʃɪŋ, ðɛn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "muvɪŋ nɔɹθ. itʃ deɪ, wɪl əv jə ən nil meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz ən ɹɪtɝn səm ə ðə pipəl tə ðɛɹ hoʊmz. bʌt doʊn taɪɝ jʊɹsɛlvz."

"We'll keep marching, then," Perrin said. "Moving north. Each day, we'll have you and Neald make gateways and return some of the people to their homes. But don't tire yourselves."

ɡɹeɪɾi nɑɾəd, aɪz hɑloʊ fɹəm fətiɡ. pɝhæps ɪt wəd bi bɛs tə weɪɾ ə fju mɔɹ deɪz bɪfɔɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ ðə pɹɑsɛs. pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd ə dɪsmɪsəl tə ðə dɛɾəkeɪtəd, ən ɡɹeɪɾi dʒɑɡd bæk daʊn ɪndə kæmp. pɛɹɪn ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ðə hɪlsaɪd, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə vɛɹiəs sɛkʃənz ə ðə kæmp əz ðə pipəl pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ði ivnɪŋ mil. ðə wæɡənz sæɾ ət ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kæmp, leɪɾən wɪð fud ðət - hi fɪɹd - wəd ɹʌn aʊt bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɹitʃ ændɝ. əɹ ʃəɾ i ɡoʊ ɝaʊn tə kɛɹhin? ðət wɑz wɛɹ i hæd læst sin ɹænd, ðoʊ hɪz vɪʒənz ə ðə mæn meɪɾ ɪt sim i wɑzn ɪn iðɝ kʌntʃɹi.

Grady nodded, eyes hollow from fatigue. Perhaps it would be best to wait a few more days before starting the process. Perrin nodded a dismissal to the Dedicated, and Grady jogged back down into camp. Perrin remained on the hillside, inspecting the various sections of the camp as the people prepared for the evening meal. The wagons sat at the center of the camp, laden with food that - he feared - would run out before he could reach Andor. Or should he go around to Cairhien? That was where he had last seen Rand, though his visions of the man made it seem he wasn't in either country.

hi daʊɾɪd ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ wəd wɛlkəm ɪm wɪð oʊpən ɑɹmz, æftɝ ðə ɹumɝz əbaʊɾ ɪm ən ðət blæstəd ɹɛɾ iɡəl bænɝ.

He doubted the Queen of Andor would welcome him with open arms, after the rumors about him and that blasted Red Eagle banner.

pɛɹɪn lɛf ðət pɹɑbləm əloʊn fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ðə kæmp sim tə bi sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn. itʃ ɹɪŋ ə tɛns sɛn ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪvz tə ðə sɛntʃɹəl fud dipoʊ tə kleɪm ðɛɹ ivnɪŋ ɹæʃənz. itʃ ɡɹup wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv ɪts oʊn milz; pɛɹɪn dʒʌst oʊvɝsɔ ðə dɪstʃɹəbjuʃən ə mətɪɹiəlz. hi meɪɾ aʊt ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝ - ə kɛɹhinɪn neɪm beɪvɪn ɹɑkʃɔ - stændɪŋ ɑn ðə bæk ʌv ə wæɡən, dilɪŋ wɪð itʃ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪv ɪn tɝn.

Perrin left that problem alone for the moment. The camp seemed to be settling in. Each ring of tents sent representatives to the central food depot to claim their evening rations. Each group was in charge of its own meals; Perrin just oversaw the distribution of materials. He made out the quartermaster - a Cairhienin named Bavin Rockshaw - standing on the back of a wagon, dealing with each representative in turn.

sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ɪz ɪnspɛkʃən, pɛɹɪn wɔk daʊn ɪndə ðə kæmp, pæsɪŋ θɹu ðə kɛɹhinɪn tɛns ɑn ðə weɪ tə hɪz oʊn tɛns, wɪtʃ wɝ wɪð ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn.

Satisfied with his inspection, Perrin walked down into the camp, passing through the Cairhienin tents on the way to his own tents, which were with the Two Rivers men.

hi tʊk ɪz ɛnhænst sɛnsɪz fəɹ ɡɹæntəd, naʊ. ðeɪ hæd kʌm əlɔŋ wɪð ðə jɛloʊɪŋ ə hɪz aɪz. moʊs pipəl ɝaʊn ɪm dɪdn sim tə noʊɾəs ðoʊz ɛnimɔɹ, bʌɾ i wɑz stɑɹkli ɹimaɪndəɾ ə ðə kɑntʃɹæst wən i mɛɾ ɛniwʌn nu. mɛni ʌv ðə kɛɹhinɪn ɹɛfjudʒiz, fəɹ ɪnstəns, pɔzd ɪn ðɛɹ leɪbɝz sɛɾɪŋ ʌp tɛns. ðeɪ wɑtʃt ɪm əz i pæst, wɪspɝɪŋ, "ɡoʊldeɪniz."

He took his enhanced senses for granted, now. They had come along with the yellowing of his eyes. Most people around him didn't seem to notice those anymore, but he was starkly reminded of the contrast when he met anyone new. Many of the Cairhienin refugees, for instance, paused in their labors setting up tents. They watched him as he passed, whispering, "Goldeneyes."

hi dɪdn mʌtʃ kɛɹ fəɹ ðə neɪm. eɪbɑɹə wɑz ðə neɪm ə hɪz fæmli, ən i bɔɹ ɪt pɹaʊdli. hi wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju hu kəd pæs ɪɾ ɑn. tʃɹɑləks hæd sin tə ðæt.

He didn't much care for the name. Aybara was the name of his family, and he bore it proudly. He was one of the few who could pass it on. Trollocs had seen to that.

hi ʃɑɾ ə ɡlæns əɾ ə nɪɹbaɪ ɡɹup ə ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz, ən ðeɪ heɪstəli tɝn bæk tə paʊndɪŋ ɪn tɛn steɪks. əz ðeɪ dɪd, pɛɹɪn pæst ə kʌpəl ə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn - tɑɾ ɑlkɑɹ ən dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝ. ðeɪ sɔ hɪm ən səluɾəd, fɪsts tə hɑɹts. tə ðɛm, pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz wɑzn ə pɝsən tə fɪɹ, bʌt wʌn tə ɹɪspɛkt, ɔlðoʊ ðeɪ dɪd stɪl wɪspɝ əbaʊt ðət naɪt hid spɛn ɪn bɹəleɪnz tɛnt. pɛɹɪn wɪʃt i kəɾ ɪskeɪp ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ðəɾ ɪvɛnt. ðə mɛn wɝ stɪl ɪnθuziæstɪk ən ɛnɝdʒaɪz baɪ ðɛɹ dɪfiɾ ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, bʌɾ ɪt hædn bɪn tu lɔŋ əɡoʊ ðət pɛɹɪn hæd fɛlt i wɑznt wɛlkəm əmʌŋ ðɛm.

He shot a glance at a nearby group of the refugees, and they hastily turned back to pounding in tent stakes. As they did, Perrin passed a couple of Two Rivers men - Tod al'Caar and Jori Congar. They saw him and saluted, fists to hearts. To them, Perrin Goldeneyes wasn't a person to fear, but one to respect, although they did still whisper about that night he'd spent in Berelain's tent. Perrin wished he could escape the shadow of that event. The men were still enthusiastic and energized by their defeat of the Shaido, but it hadn't been too long ago that Perrin had felt he wasn't welcome among them.

stɪl, fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ðiz tu sim tə hæv sɛɾ əsaɪd ðət dɪsplɛʒɝ. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ səluɾəd.

Still, for the moment, these two seemed to have set aside that displeasure. Instead, they saluted.

hæd ðeɪ fɝɡɑɾən ðət pɛɹɪn hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð ðɛm? wʌɾ ə ðə taɪmz wən dʒɔɹi hæd meɪd spɔɹɾ ə pɛɹɪnz sloʊ tʌŋ, əɹ ðə taɪmz wən hid stɑp baɪ ðə fɔɹdʒ tə bɹæɡ əbaʊt wɪtʃ ɡɝlz hid mænədʒ tə stil ə kɪs fɹʌm?

Had they forgotten that Perrin had grown up with them? What of the times when Jori had made sport of Perrin's slow tongue, or the times when he'd stopped by the forge to brag about which girls he'd managed to steal a kiss from?

pɛɹɪn dʒʌs nɑɾəd bæk. noʊ jus ɪn dɪɡɪŋ ʌp ðə pæst, nɑt wən ðɛɹ əlidʒəns tə "pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz" hæd hɛlpt ɹɛskju feɪl. ðoʊ, əz i lɛf ðɛm, hɪz tu-kin ɪɹz kɑt ðə tu ʌv əm tʃæɾɪŋ əbaʊt ðə bæɾəl, dʒʌst ə fju deɪz pæst, ən ðɛɹ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. wʌn ə ðɛm stɪl smɛld laɪk blʌd; hi hædn klin ɪz buts. hi pɹɑbli dɪdn ivən noʊɾəs ðə blʌdsteɪn mʌd.

Perrin just nodded back. No use in digging up the past, not when their allegiance to "Perrin Goldeneyes" had helped rescue Faile. Though, as he left them, his too-keen ears caught the two of them chatting about the battle, just a few days past, and their part of it. One of them still smelled like blood; he hadn't cleaned his boots. He probably didn't even notice the bloodstained mud.

səmtaɪmz, pɛɹɪn wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɪz sɛnsɪz wɝn æktʃəli  ɛni bɛɾɝ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz. hi tʊk ðə taɪm tə noʊɾəs θɪŋz ðəɾ ʌðɝz ɪɡnɔɹd. haʊ kəd ðeɪ mɪs ðət sɛn ə blʌd? ən ðə kɹɪsp ɛɹ ə ðə maʊntənz tə ðə nɔɹθ? ɪt smɛld ə hoʊm, ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ mɛni liɡz fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɪf ʌðɝ mɛn tʊk ðə taɪm tə kloʊz ðɛɹ aɪz ən peɪ ətɛnʃən, wəd ðeɪ bi eɪbəl tə smɛl wʌɾ i dɪd? ɪf ðeɪ oʊpən ðoʊz aɪz ən lʊkt kloʊsɝ ət ðə wɝld ɝaʊn ðɛm, wəd mɛn kɔl ðɛɹ aɪz "kin" əz ðeɪ dɪd pɛɹɪnz?

Sometimes, Perrin wondered if his senses weren't actually any better than anyone else's. He took the time to notice things that others ignored. How could they miss that scent of blood? And the crisp air of the mountains to the north? It smelled of home, though they were many leagues from the Two Rivers. If other men took the time to close their eyes and pay attention, would they be able to smell what he did? If they opened those eyes and looked closer at the world around them, would men call their eyes "keen" as they did Perrin's?

noʊ. ðət wɑz dʒʌs fænsi. hɪz sɛnsɪz wɝ bɛɾɝ; hɪz kɪnʃɪp wɪð ðə wʊlvz hæd tʃeɪnʒd hɪm. hi hædn θɔɾ ə ðət kɪnʃɪp ɪn ə waɪl - hid bɪn tu foʊkəst ɑn feɪl. bʌt hid stɑp filɪŋ soʊ sɛlf-kɑnʃəs əbaʊɾ ɪz aɪz. ðeɪ wɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɪm. noʊ jus ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm.

No. That was just fancy. His senses were better; his kinship with the wolves had changed him. He hadn't thought of that kinship in a while - he'd been too focused on Faile. But he'd stopped feeling so self-conscious about his eyes. They were part of him. No use grumbling about them.

ən jɛt, ðət ɹeɪdʒ i fɛlt wən i fɔt . . . ðət lɔs ə kəntʃɹoʊl. ɪt wɝid hɪm, mɔɹ ən mɔɹ.

And yet, that rage he felt when he fought . . . that loss of control. It worried him, more and more.

ðə fɝs taɪm hid fɛlt ɪt hæd bɪn ðət naɪt, soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, faɪɾɪŋ waɪtkloʊks. fəɹ ə taɪm, pɛɹɪn hædnt noʊn ɪf i wɑz ə wʊlf əɹ ə mæn.

The first time he'd felt it had been that night, so long ago, fighting Whitecloaks. For a time, Perrin hadn't known if he was a wolf or a man.

ən naʊ - dʊɹɪŋ wʌn ə hɪz ɹisən vɪzəts tə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim - hid tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɑpɝ. ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, dɛθ wɑz faɪnəl. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɔlmoʊs lɔs hɪmsɛlf ðət deɪ. θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪɾ əweɪkən oʊl fɪɹz, fɪɹz hid ʃʌvd əsaɪd. fɪɹz ɹɪleɪɾɪŋ tə ə mæn, bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk ə wʊlf, lɑkt ɪn ə keɪdʒ.

And now - during one of his recent visits to the wolf dream - he'd tried to kill Hopper. In the wolf dream, death was final. Perrin had almost lost himself that day. Thinking of it awakened old fears, fears he'd shoved aside. Fears relating to a man, behaving like a wolf, locked in a cage.

hi kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə pæθweɪ tə hɪz tɛnt, meɪkɪŋ səm dɪsɪʒənz. hid pɝsud feɪl wɪð dɪtɝməneɪʃən, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə wʊlf dʒɹim əz hiɾ əvɔɪɾəd ɔl ə hɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾiz. hid kleɪm ðət nʌθɪŋ ɛls hæd mæɾɝd. bʌɾ i nu ðət ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt. hid foʊkəst ɑn feɪl kəz i lʌvd əɹ soʊ mʌtʃ, bʌt - ɪn ədɪʃən - hid dʌn soʊ kəz ɪt hæd bɪn kənvinjənt. hɝ ɹɛskju hæd bɪn ən ɪkskjus tə əvɔɪd θɪŋz laɪk ɪz dɪskʌmfɝt wɪð liɾɝʃɪp ən ðə blɝd tʃɹus bɪtwin hɪmsɛlf ən ðə wʊlf ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf.

He continued down the pathway to his tent, making some decisions. He'd pursued Faile with determination, avoiding the wolf dream as he'd avoided all of his responsibilities. He'd claimed that nothing else had mattered. But he knew that the truth was much more difficult. He'd focused on Faile because he loved her so much, but - in addition - he'd done so because it had been convenient. Her rescue had been an excuse to avoid things like his discomfort with leadership and the blurred truce between himself and the wolf inside of himself.

hi hæd ɹɛskjud feɪl, bʌt soʊ mɛni θɪŋz wɝ stɪl ɹɔŋ. ði ænsɝz maɪt laɪ ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz.

He had rescued Faile, but so many things were still wrong. The answers might lie in his dreams.

ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɹɪtɝn.

It was time to return.

tʃæptɝ eɪtin

CHAPTER 18

eɪ mɛsədʒ ɪn heɪst sɪuən fɹoʊz - bæskəɾ ə dɝɾi lɔnʒɹi ɑn əɹ hɪp - ðə moʊmənt ʃi wɔkt ɪndə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp. ɪt wɑz əɹ oʊn lɔnʒɹi, ðɪs taɪm. ʃid faɪnəli ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi dɪdnt nid tə də boʊθ hɝz ən bɹaɪnz. waɪ nɑt lɛt ðə nɑvəsɪz pʊɾ ɪn səm taɪm ɑn əɹ wɑʃɪŋ? ðəɹ wɝ sɝɾənli ɪnʌf ə ðɛm ðiz deɪz.

A Message in Haste Siuan froze - basket of dirty laundry on her hip - the moment she walked into the Aes Sedai camp. It was her own laundry, this time. She'd finally realized that she didn't need to do both hers and Bryne's. Why not let the novices put in some time on her washing? There were certainly enough of them these days.

ən ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm kɹaʊɾəd ðə wɔkweɪ ɝaʊn ðə pəvɪljən ət ðə sɛntɝ ə kæmp. ðeɪ stʊɾ ɑɹm-tə-ɑɹm, ə wɔl ʌv waɪt tɑp baɪ hɛdz ə hɛɹ ɪn ɛvɹi nætʃɹəl hju. noʊ ɔɹɾənɛɹi miɾɪŋ ə ðə hɔl wʊɾə dʒɹɔn sətʃ ətɛnʃən. sʌmθɪŋ mʌs bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn.

And every one of them crowded the walkway around the pavilion at the center of camp. They stood arm-to-arm, a wall of white topped by heads of hair in every natural hue. No ordinary meeting of the Hall would have drawn such attention. Something must be going on.

sɪuən sɛt ðə wɪkɝ lɔnʒɹi bæskəɾ ɑn ə stʌmp, ðən pʊld ə taʊəl oʊvɝ ɪt. ʃi dɪdn tʃɹʌs ðət skaɪ, ɔlðoʊ ɪt hædn ɹeɪn mɔɹ ðən ði əkeɪʒənəl dʒɹɪzəl ɪn ðə pæst wik. doʊn tʃɹʌst ə dɑkmæstɝz skaɪ. wɝdz tə lɪv baɪ. ivən ɪf ðə kɑnsəkwəns oʊnli mɛn ə bæskəɾ ʌv wɛt kloʊðɪŋ, sɔɪld ət ðæt.

Siuan set the wicker laundry basket on a stump, then pulled a towel over it. She didn't trust that sky, although it hadn't rained more than the occasional drizzle in the past week. Don't trust a dockmaster's sky. Words to live by. Even if the consequence only meant a basket of wet clothing, soiled at that.

ʃi hɝiɾ əkɹɔs ðə dɝt ɹoʊɾ ən stɛpt ʌp ɑntu wʌn ə ðə wʊɾən wɔkweɪz. ðə ɹʌf bɔɹdz ʃɪftəd slaɪtli ʌndɝfʊɾ ən kɹikt wɪð əɹ fʊtfɔlz əz ʃi hɝid təwɔɹdz ðə pəvɪljən.

She hurried across the dirt road and stepped up onto one of the wooden walkways. The rough boards shifted slightly underfoot and creaked with her footfalls as she hurried towards the pavilion.

ðəɹ wɑz tɔk ə ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ ðə wɔkweɪz wɪð sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ pɝmənənt, pɝhæps əz ɪkspɛnsɪv əz peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz.

There was talk of replacing the walkways with something more permanent, perhaps as expensive as paving stones.

ʃi ɹitʃt ðə bæks ə ðə ɡæðɝd wɪmən. ðə læs miɾɪŋ ə ðə hɔl ðət hæd dʒɹɔn ðɪs lɛvəl ʌv ətɛnʃən hæd ɹɪvil ðəɾ æʃəmən hæd bɑndəd sɪstɝz ən ðət ðə teɪn ɪtsɛlf hæd bɪn klɛnzd. laɪt sɛn ðət ðəɹ wɝn ɛni sɝpɹaɪzəz ə ðət saɪz weɪɾɪŋ! hɝ nɝvz wɝ tɔɾ ɪnʌf, dilɪŋ wɪð ɡɛɹɪθ blʌɾi bɹaɪn. sədʒɛstɪŋ ðət ʃi lɛɾ ɪm titʃ əɹ haʊ tə hoʊld ə sɔɹd, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. ʃid nɛvɝ θɔt ðət sɔɹdz wɝ mʌtʃ juz. bɪsaɪdz, hu ɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ə wɛpən, faɪɾɪŋ laɪk ə kɹeɪzd il? ɑnəsli, ðət mæn.

She reached the backs of the gathered women. The last meeting of the Hall that had drawn this level of attention had revealed that Asha'man had bonded sisters and that the taint itself had been cleansed. Light send that there weren't any surprises of that size waiting! Her nerves were taut enough, dealing with Gareth bloody Bryne. Suggesting that she let him teach her how to hold a sword, just in case. She'd never thought that swords were much use. Besides, who ever heard of an Aes Sedai with a weapon, fighting like a crazed Aiel? Honestly, that man.

ʃi bʊliɾ əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə nɑvəsɪz, ənɔɪd ðət ʃi hæd tə ɡɛt ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə meɪk əm lɛɾ əɹ pæs. ðeɪ ɡeɪv weɪ əz sun əz ðeɪ sɔ ə sɪstɝ pæsɪŋ θɹu ðɛm, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ soʊ dɪstʃɹæktəd ðəɾ ɪt tʊk wɝk tə muv əm aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. ʃi tʃaɪɾɪd ə fju ʌv əm fəɹ nɑt biɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ duɾiz. wɛɹ wɑz tiɑnə? ʃi ʃʊɾə hæd ðiz ɡɝlz bæk tə ðɛɹ tʃɔɹz. ɪf ɹænd ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf blʌɾi əpɪɹɾ ɪn kæmp, ðə nɑvəsɪz ʃəd kəntɪnju ðɛɹ lɛsənz!

She bullied her way through the novices, annoyed that she had to get their attention in order to make them let her pass. They gave way as soon as they saw a sister passing through them, of course, but they were so distracted that it took work to move them out of the way. She chided a few of them for not being about their duties. Where was Tiana? She should have had these girls back to their chores. If Rand al'Thor himself bloody appeared in camp, the novices should continue their lessons!

faɪnəli, nɪɹ ðə pəvɪljən flæps, ʃi faʊn ðə wʊmən ʃiɾ ɪkspɛktəd. ʃɛɹiəm, əz ɛɡwinz kipɝ, kʊdn ɛntɝ ðə hɔl wɪθaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn. ən soʊ ʃi wɑz ɹədus tə weɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli bɛɾɝ ðən stuɪŋ bæk ɪn əɹ tɛnt.

Finally, near the pavilion flaps, she found the woman she'd expected. Sheriam, as Egwene's Keeper, couldn't enter the Hall without the Amyrlin. And so she was reduced to waiting outside. It was probably better than stewing back in her tent.

ðə faɪɝ-hɛɹd wʊmən hæd lɔst ə fɛɹ bɪɾ ə hɝ plʌmpnəs oʊvɝ ðə pɹiviəs wiks. ʃi ɹɪli niɾəd tə kəmɪʃən nu dʒɹɛsəz; hɝ oʊld wʌnz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə hæŋ ɑn hɝ. stɪl, ʃi sim tə hæv ɹiɡeɪn səm kɑm ɹisənli, tə bi lɛs ɪɹæɾɪk. pɝhæps wʌtɛvɝ hæd bɪn eɪlɪŋ əɹ hæd pæst. ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz ɪnsɪstəd ðət nʌθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs.

The fire-haired woman had lost a fair bit of her plumpness over the previous weeks. She really needed to commission new dresses; her old ones were beginning to hang on her. Still, she seemed to have regained some calm recently, to be less erratic. Perhaps whatever had been ailing her had passed. She'd always insisted that nothing was wrong in the first place.

"fɪʃ ɡʌts," sɪuən ɡɹʌmbəld əz ə nɑvəs æksədɛntəli ɛlboʊd hɝ. sɪuən ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡɝl, hu wɪltɪɾ ən skɝiɾ əweɪ, hɝ fæmli ʌv nɑvəsɪz ɹɪlʌktənli fɑloʊɪŋ. sɪuən tɝn bæk tə ʃɛɹiəm.

"Fish guts," Siuan grumbled as a novice accidentally elbowed her. Siuan glared at the girl, who wilted and scurried away, her family of novices reluctantly following. Siuan turned back to Sheriam.

"soʊ wʌɾ ɪz ɪt? dɪd wʌn ə ðə steɪbəl bɔɪz tɝn aʊt tə bi ðə kɪŋ ə tiɹ?"

"So what is it? Did one of the stable boys turn out to be the King of Tear?"

ʃɛɹiəm ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "ɪleɪɾə hæz tʃɹævlɪŋ."

Sheriam raised an eyebrow. "Elaida has Traveling."

"wʌt? " sɪuən æskt, ɡlænsɪŋ ɪndə ðə tɛnt. ðə sits wɝ fɪld wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən læŋki æʃmɑneɪl - ʌv ðə ɡɹeɪ - wɑz ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ðɛm. waɪ hædn ðɪs miɾɪŋ bɪn sil tə ðə fleɪm?

"What? " Siuan asked, glancing into the tent. The seats were filled with Aes Sedai, and lanky Ashmanaille - of the Gray - was addressing them. Why hadn't this meeting been Sealed to the Flame?

ʃɛɹiəm nɑɾəd. "wi faʊn aʊt wən æʃmɑneɪl wɑz sɛn tə kəlɛk fɹəm kændɝ." tʃɹɪbjuts wɝ wʌn ə ðə meɪn sɔɹsəz ʌv ɪnkʌm fəɹ ɛɡwinz ɛɛs sədaɪ. fəɹ mɛni sɛntʃɝiz, itʃ kɪŋdəm hæd sɛn sətʃ doʊneɪʃənz tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðə waɪt taʊɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɪlaɪɾ ɑn ðəɾ ɪnkʌm - ɪt hæd fɑɹ bɛɾɝ minz ə səsteɪnɪŋ ɪtsɛlf, wʌnz ðət dɪdn ɹɪlaɪ ɑn aʊtsaɪd dʒɛnɝɑsəɾi. stɪl, tʃɹɪbjuts wɝ nɛvɝ tɝn əweɪ, ən mɛni ʌv ðə bɔɹɾɝlənd kɪŋdəmz stɪl hɛl tə ði oʊld weɪz.

Sheriam nodded. "We found out when Ashmanaille was sent to collect from Kandor." Tributes were one of the main sources of income for Egwene's Aes Sedai. For many centuries, each kingdom had sent such donations to Tar Valon. The White Tower no longer relied on that income - it had far better means of sustaining itself, ones that didn't rely on outside generosity. Still, tributes were never turned away, and many of the Borderland kingdoms still held to the old ways.

bɪfɔɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ bɹoʊk, wʌn ʌv æʃmɑneɪlz duɾiz hæd bɪn tə kip tʃɹæk ə ðiz doʊneɪʃənz ən sɛn mʌnθli θæŋks ɑn bɪhæf ə ði æmɪɝlɪn. ðə splɪɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðə dɪskʌvɝi ʌv tʃɹævlɪŋ, hæd meɪɾ ɪt vɛɹi izi fəɹ ɛɡwinz ɛɛs sədaɪ tə sɛn ə dɛləɡeɪʃən ən kəlɛk tʃɹɪbjuts ɪn pɝsən. ðə kændɔɹi tʃif klɝk hædn kɛɹd wɪtʃ ə ðə tu waɪt taʊɝ saɪdz i səpɔɹɾəd, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə tʃɹɪbjut wɑz sɛnt, ən hæd bɪn hæpi tə dɪlɪvɝ ðə mʌni tə æʃmɑneɪl dɝɛkli.

Before the White Tower broke, one of Ashmanaille's duties had been to keep track of these donations and send monthly thanks on behalf of the Amyrlin. The split of the White Tower, and the discovery of Traveling, had made it very easy for Egwene's Aes Sedai to send a delegation and collect tributes in person. The Kandori chief clerk hadn't cared which of the two White Tower sides he supported, so long as the tribute was sent, and had been happy to deliver the money to Ashmanaille directly.

ðə sidʒ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd meɪɾ ɪt sɪmpəl tə saɪfən ðɪs kɔɪn əweɪ fɹəm tʃɹɪbjuts ðət maɪɾ əv ɡɔn tə ɪleɪɾə, ɪnstɛd juzɪŋ əm tə peɪ bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz. ə vɛɹi nit twɪst ə feɪt. bʌt noʊ si ɹɪmeɪn kɑm fɝɛvɝ.

The siege of Tar Valon had made it simple to siphon this coin away from tributes that might have gone to Elaida, instead using them to pay Bryne's soldiers. A very neat twist of fate. But no sea remained calm forever.

"ðə tʃif klɝk wɑz kwaɪt lɪvɪd," æʃmɑneɪl sɛɾ ɪn əɹ noʊ-nɑnsɛns vɔɪs. " 'aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi peɪd jəɹ mʌni ðɪs mʌnθ,' hi toʊl mi. 'aɪ ɡeɪv ɪt tə ə wʊmən u keɪm nɑt wʌn deɪ ɡɔn. ðə wʊmən bɔɹ ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf, sil pɹɑpɝli, wɪtʃ toʊl mi tə ɡɪv ðə mʌni oʊnli tə ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ.' "

"The chief clerk was quite livid," Ashmanaille said in her no-nonsense voice. " 'I already paid your money this month,' he told me. 'I gave it to a woman who came not one day gone. The woman bore a letter from the Amyrlin herself, sealed properly, which told me to give the money only to a member of the Red Ajah.' "

"ðɪs dʌzn seɪ fəɹ sɝɾən ɪleɪɾə hæz tʃɹævlɪŋ," ɹoʊmændə noʊɾəd fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛnt. "ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ cʊɾə ɡɑɾən tə kændɝ baɪ ʌðɝ minz."

"This doesn't say for certain Elaida has Traveling," Romanda noted from inside the tent. "The Red sister could have gotten to Kandor by other means."

æʃmɑneɪl ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ðeɪ sɔ ə ɡeɪtweɪ meɪd. ðə tʃif klɝk dɪskʌvɝɾ ən əkaʊntɪŋ ɛɹɝ ən sɛn ə skɹaɪb aʊɾ æftɝ ɪleɪɾəz dɛləɡeɪʃən tə ɡɪv əm ə fju ɛkstʃɹə kɔɪnz. ðə mæn dɪskɹaɪbd wʌɾ i sɔ pɝfəkli. ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ə blæk hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ. ɪt stʌn ɪm soʊ dipli ðəɾ i kɔl fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹd - bʌt baɪ ðən ɪleɪɾəz pipəl wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɔn. aɪ ɪntɛɹəɡeɪɾɪd ɪm maɪsɛlf."

Ashmanaille shook her head. "They saw a gateway made. The chief clerk discovered an accounting error and sent a scribe out after Elaida's delegation to give them a few extra coins. The man described what he saw perfectly. The horses were riding through a black hole in the air. It stunned him so deeply that he called for the guard - but by then Elaida's people were already gone. I interrogated him myself."

"aɪ dɪslaɪk tʃɹʌstɪŋ ðə wɝɾ ʌv wʌn mæn," sɛd mɔɹiə, sɪɾɪŋ nɪɹ ðə fɹʌn ə ðə ɡɹup.

"I dislike trusting the word of one man," said Moria, sitting near the front of the group.

"ðə tʃif klɝk dɪskɹaɪbd ɪn dɪteɪl ðə wʊmən u tʊk ðə mʌni fɹəm hɪm," æʃmɑneɪl sɛd.

"The chief clerk described in detail the woman who took the money from him," Ashmanaille said.

"aɪ æm kɑnfəɾənt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz nɛziɾə. pɝhæps wi kəd dɪskʌvɝ ɪf ʃiz ɪn ðə taʊɝ? ðət wəd ɡɪv əs fɝðɝ pɹuf."

"I am confident that it was Nesita. Perhaps we could discover if she is in the Tower? That would give us further proof."

ʌðɝz ɹeɪzd əbdʒɛkʃənz, bʌt sɪuən sis tə lɪsən kloʊsli. pɝhæps ðɪs wɑz ə vɛɹi klɛvɝ ɹuz ɪntɛndəd tə dɪstʃɹæk ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ kʊdn teɪk ðət tʃæns. laɪt! wɑz ʃi ði oʊnli wʌn wɪð ə hɛɾ ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz?

Others raised objections, but Siuan ceased to listen closely. Perhaps this was a very clever ruse intended to distract them, but they couldn't take that chance. Light! Was she the only one with a head on her shoulders?

ʃi ɡɹæb ðə nɪɹəs nɑvəs, ə maʊzi ɡɝl u wɑz pɹɑbli oʊldɝ ðən ʃi lʊkt - ʃiɾ əv tə bi, sɪns ʃi lʊk noʊ oʊldɝ ðən naɪn. "aɪ niɾ ə kɝiɝ," sɪuən ɪnfɔɹm hɝ. "fɛtʃ wʌn ə ðə mɛsənʒɝz lɔɹd bɹaɪn lɛft ət ðə kæmp fəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ nuz tə hɪm. kwɪkli."

She grabbed the nearest novice, a mousy girl who was probably older than she looked - she'd have to be, since she looked no older than nine. "I need a courier," Siuan informed her. "Fetch one of the messengers Lord Bryne left at the camp for running news to him. Quickly."

ðə ɡɝl jɛlpt, dæʃɪŋ əweɪ.

The girl yelped, dashing away.

"wʌt wɑz ðəɾ əbaʊt?" ʃɛɹiəm æskt.

"What was that about?" Sheriam asked.

"seɪvɪŋ əɹ lɪvz," sɪuən sɛd, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə kɹaʊɾɪŋ nɑvəsɪz. "ɔl ɹaɪt!" ʃi ɡɹaʊld.

"Saving our lives," Siuan said, glaring at the crowding novices. "All right!" she growled.

"ɪnʌf ɡɔkɪŋ! ɪf jəɹ klæsəz ɑɹ poʊstpoʊn kəz ə ðɪs fiæskoʊ, ðən faɪn səm wɝk tə du.

"Enough gawking! If your classes are postponed because of this fiasco, then find some work to do.

ɛni nɑvəs stɪl stændɪŋ ɑn ðɪs wɔkweɪ ɪn tɛn sɛkənz wɪl faɪn hɝsɛlf duɪŋ pɛnəns əntɪl ʃi kæn kaʊn stʃɹeɪt!"

Any novice still standing on this walkway in ten seconds will find herself doing penance until she can't count straight!"

ðəɾ ɪnɪʃieɪɾəd ə mæs ɛksəɾəs ʌv waɪt, ðə fæmliz ʌv wɪmən bʌsəlɪŋ əweɪ wɪð hɝid stɛps. ɪn moʊməns, oʊnli ðə smɔl ɡɹup ʌv æksɛptɪd ɹɪmeɪnd, əlɔŋ wɪð ʃɛɹiəm ən sɪuən. ði æksɛptɪd kɹɪnʒd wən sɪuən ɡlænst ət ðɛm, bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ. pɑɹɾ ə ðə pɹɪvlədʒ ə biɪŋ ən æksɛptɪd wɑz ɪnkɹis fɹiɾəm. bɪsaɪdz, əz lɔŋ əz sɪuən kəd muv wɪθaʊt bʌmpɪŋ sʌmwʌn, ʃi wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd.

That initiated a mass exodus of white, the families of women bustling away with hurried steps. In moments, only the small group of Accepted remained, along with Sheriam and Siuan. The Accepted cringed when Siuan glanced at them, but she said nothing. Part of the privilege of being an Accepted was increased freedom. Besides, as long as Siuan could move without bumping someone, she was satisfied.

"waɪ wɑzn ðɪs miɾɪŋ sil tə ðə fleɪm ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs?" ʃi æskt ʃɛɹiəm.

"Why wasn't this meeting Sealed to the Flame in the first place?" she asked Sheriam.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ʃɛɹiəm ədmɪɾəd, ɡlænsɪŋ ɪndə ðə lɑɹdʒ tɛnt. "ɪts dɔntɪŋ nuz, ɪf ɪts tʃɹu."

"I don't know," Sheriam admitted, glancing into the large tent. "It's daunting news, if it's true."

"ðɪs wɑz baʊn tə əkɝ ɪvɛntʃəwəli," sɪuən sɛd, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ ðət kɑm ɑn ði ɪnsaɪd. "nuz ə tʃɹævlɪŋ əz tə bi spɹɛɾɪŋ."

"This was bound to occur eventually," Siuan said, though she was nowhere near that calm on the inside. "News of Traveling has to be spreading."

wʌt hæpənd? ʃi θɔt. ðeɪ dɪdn bɹeɪk ɛɡwin, dɪd ðeɪ? laɪt sɛn ɪt wɑzn əɹ əɹ lin u wɑz fɔɹs tə ɡɪv ʌp ðɪs sikɹət. bioʊnɪn. ɪt hæd tə bi hɝ. bɝn ɪɾ ɔl!

What happened? she thought. They didn't break Egwene, did they? Light send it wasn't her or Leane who was forced to give up this secret. Beonin. It had to be her. Burn it all!

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "laɪt sɛn ðət wi kən kip tʃɹævlɪŋ sikɹət fɹəm ðə sintʃæn. wən ðeɪ də əsɔl ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wɪl wɑn ət lis ðəɾ ædvæntɪdʒ."

She shook her head. "Light send that we can keep Traveling secret from the Seanchan. When they do assault the White Tower, we'll want at least that advantage."

ʃɛɹiəm aɪd hɝ, skɛptɪsɪzəm ʃoʊɪŋ. moʊst ə ðə sɪstɝz dɪdn bɪliv ɛɡwinz dʒɹimɪŋ ə ði ətæk. fulz - ðeɪ wɑntəd tə kætʃ ðə fɪʃ, bʌt dɪdnt wɑnə ɡʌɾ ɪt. jə dɪdn ɹeɪz ə wʊmən tə æmɪɝlɪn, ðən tʃɹiɾ əɹ wɔɹnɪŋz laɪtli.

Sheriam eyed her, skepticism showing. Most of the sisters didn't believe Egwene's Dreaming of the attack. Fools - they wanted to catch the fish, but didn't want to gut it. You didn't raise a woman to Amyrlin, then treat her warnings lightly.

sɪuən weɪɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli, tæpɪŋ əɹ fʊt, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛnt. dʒʌst əz ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wʌndɝ ɪf ʃid nid tə sɛn ənʌðɝ nɑvəs, wʌn ə bɹaɪnz kɝiɝz tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp tə ðə tɛn ɑn hɔɹsbæk. ði ɪl-tɛmpɝd bɹuɾ i wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɑz mɪdnaɪt blæk wɪð waɪt dʒʌst əbʌv ðə hʊvz, ən ɪt snɔɹɾɪd ət sɪuən əz ðə ɹaɪɾɝ pʊld ʌp ʃɔɹt, wɛɹɪŋ ə nit junəfɔɹm ən kloʊs- kɹɑp bɹaʊn hɛɹ. dɪɾ i hæv tə bɹɪŋ ðət kɹitʃɝ wɪð hɪm?

Siuan waited impatiently, tapping her foot, listening to the conversation inside the tent. Just as she was beginning to wonder if she'd need to send another novice, one of Bryne's couriers trotted up to the tent on horseback. The ill-tempered brute he was riding was midnight black with white just above the hooves, and it snorted at Siuan as the rider pulled up short, wearing a neat uniform and close- cropped brown hair. Did he have to bring that creature with him?

"ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ðə mæn æskt, boʊɪŋ tə hɝ fɹəm hɔɹsbæk. "ju hæv ə mɛsədʒ fəɹ lɔɹd bɹaɪn?"

"Aes Sedai?" the man asked, bowing to her from horseback. "You have a message for Lord Bryne?"

"jɛs," sɪuən sɛd. "æn jəl si ɪt dɪlɪvɝd wɪð ɔl heɪst. jə ʌndɝstæn mi? ɔl ʌv əɹ laɪvz kəd dɪpɛn ɑn ɪt."

"Yes," Siuan said. "And you'll see it delivered with all haste. You understand me? All of our lives could depend on it."

ðə soʊlʒɝ nɑɾəd ʃɑɹpli.

The soldier nodded sharply.

"tɛl lɔɹd bɹaɪn . . ." sɪuən bɪɡæn. "tɛl ɪm tə wɑtʃ ɪz flæŋks. əɹ ɛnəmi hæz bɪn tɔt ðə mɛθəd wi juz tə ɡɛt hɪɹ."

"Tell Lord Bryne . . ." Siuan began. "Tell him to watch his flanks. Our enemy has been taught the method we used to get here."

"ɪt ʃæl bi dʌn."

"It shall be done."

"ɹɪpiɾ ɪt bæk tə mi," sɪuən sɛd.

"Repeat it back to me," Siuan said.

"ʌv kɔɹs, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ðə slɛndɝ mæn sɛd, boʊɪŋ əɡɛn. "dʒʌst soʊ jə noʊ, aɪ hæv bɪn ə mɛsənʒɝ ɪn ðə dʒɛnɝəlz kəmæn fəɹ oʊvɝ ə dɛkeɪd. maɪ mɛmɹi - "

"Of course, Aes Sedai," the slender man said, bowing again. "Just so you know, I have been a messenger in the general's command for over a decade. My memory - "

"stɑp," sɪuən ɪntɝʌptɪd. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ lɔŋ juv bɪn duɪŋ ðɪs. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ ɡʊd jəɹ mɛmɹi ɪz. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ ɪf, baɪ səm twɪst ə feɪt, juv bɪn æsk tə ɹʌn ðɪs vɛɹi seɪm mɛsədʒ ə θaʊzən taɪmz bɪfɔɹ. jəl ɹɪpiɾ ɪt bæk tə mi."

"Stop," Siuan interrupted. "I don't care how long you've been doing this. I don't care how good your memory is. I don't care if, by some twist of fate, you've been asked to run this very same message a thousand times before. You will repeat it back to me."

"ʌm, jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪm tə tɛl ðə lɔɹd dʒɛnɝəl tə wɑtʃ ɪz flæŋks. əɹ ɛnəmi hæz bɪn tɔt ðə mɛθəd wi juz tə ɡɛt hɪɹ."

"Um, yes, Aes Sedai. I'm to tell the Lord General to watch his flanks. Our enemy has been taught the method we used to get here."

"ɡʊd. ɡoʊ."

"Good. Go."

ðə mæn nɑɾəd.

The man nodded.

"naʊ!"

"Now!"

hi ɹɪɹd ðəɾ ɑfəl hɔɹs ən ɡæləpt aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp, kloʊk flæpɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

He reared that awful horse and galloped out of the camp, cloak flapping behind him.

"wʌt wɑz ðəɾ əbaʊt?" ʃɛɹiəm æskt, ɡlænsɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə pɹoʊsiɾɪŋz ɪnsaɪd ðə hɔl.

"What was that about?" Sheriam asked, glancing away from the proceedings inside the Hall.

"meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən wi doʊnt weɪk ʌp wɪð ɪleɪɾəz ɑɹmi sɝaʊndɪŋ ʌs," sɪuən sɛd. "aɪl bɛɾ ɪm ði oʊnli wʌn u θɔt tə wɔɹn əɹ dʒɛnɝəl ðət ði ɛnəmi meɪ hæv dʒʌst əndʌn əɹ bɪɡəs tæktɪkəl ædvæntɪdʒ. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ ə sidʒ."

"Making certain we don't wake up with Elaida's army surrounding us," Siuan said. "I'll bet I'm the only one who thought to warn our general that the enemy may have just undone our biggest tactical advantage. So much for a siege."

ʃɛɹiəm fɹaʊnd, əz ɪf ʃi hædn kənsɪɾɝd ðæt. ʃi wʊdn bi əloʊn. oʊ, səm wəd θɪŋk ə bɹaɪn, ən wəd bi plænɪŋ tə sɛnd wɝd tə ðə dʒɛnɝəl ɪvɛntʃəwəli. bʌt fəɹ mɛni, ðə kətæstʃɹəfi hɪɹ wɑzn ðə fæk ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə kəd naʊ muv əɹ ɑɹmiz tə flæŋk ðɛm, əɹ ðət naʊ bɹaɪnz sidʒ wɑz jusləs. ðə kətæstʃɹəfi wəd bi mɔɹ pɝsənəl fəɹ ðɛm: ðə nɑlədʒ ðeɪd wɝk tə kip sikɹət hæd fɔlən ɪndə ðə hænz ʌv ʌðɝz. tʃɹævlɪŋ wɑz ðɛɹz, ən naʊ ɪleɪɾə hæɾ ɪt! vɛɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪndɪɡneɪʃən fɝst, ɪmpləkeɪʃən sɛkənd.

Sheriam frowned, as if she hadn't considered that. She wouldn't be alone. Oh, some would think of Bryne, and would be planning to send word to the general eventually. But for many, the catastrophe here wasn't the fact that Elaida could now move her armies to flank them, or that now Bryne's siege was useless. The catastrophe would be more personal for them: the knowledge they'd worked to keep secret had fallen into the hands of others. Traveling was theirs, and now Elaida had it! Very Aes Sedai. Indignation first, implication second.

əɹ pɝhæps sɪuən wɑz dʒʌs filɪŋ bɪɾɝ. sʌmwʌn ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛn faɪnəli θɔt tə kɔl fəɹ ðə miɾɪŋ tə bi sil tə ðə fleɪm, ən soʊ sɪuən wɪθdʒɹu, stɛpɪŋ ɔf ðə wɔkweɪ ən ɑntu ðə hɑɹd-pækt ɝθ. nɑvəsɪz skʌɾəld ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt, hɛdz baʊd tə əvɔɪɾ əɹ aɪz, ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ kwɪk tə kɝtsi. aɪ hævən bɪn duɪŋ ə vɛɹi ɡʊd dʒɑb ʌv æktɪŋ wik tədeɪ, sɪuən θɔt wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs.

Or perhaps Siuan was just feeling bitter. Someone inside the tent finally thought to call for the meeting to be Sealed to the Flame, and so Siuan withdrew, stepping off the walkway and onto the hard-packed earth. Novices scuttled this way and that, heads bowed to avoid her eyes, though they were quick to curtsy. I haven't been doing a very good job of acting weak today, Siuan thought with a grimace.

ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz kɹʌmbəlɪŋ. ði ədʒəz wikənd wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð pɛɾi ɪnfaɪɾɪŋ. ivən hɪɹ, ɪn ɛɡwinz kæmp, mɔɹ taɪm wɑz spɛn pɑlətɪkɪŋ ðən pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə kʌmɪŋ stɔɹm.

The White Tower was crumbling. The Ajahs weakened one another with petty infighting. Even here, in Egwene's camp, more time was spent politicking than preparing for the coming storm.

ən sɪuən wɑz pɑɹʃəli ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ðoʊz feɪljɝz.

And Siuan was partially responsible for those failures.

ɪleɪɾə ən əɹ ədʒɑ sɝɾənli bɔɹ ðə laɪənfɪʃəz ʃɛɹ ə ðə bleɪm. bʌt wəd ðə taʊɝ əv splɪɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs ɪf sɪuən hæd fɑstɝd koʊɑpɝeɪʃən bɪtwin ði ədʒəz? ɪleɪɾə hædn hæd ðət lɔŋ tə wɝk. ɛvɹi ɹɪf ðəɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ kəd laɪkli bi tʃɹeɪs bæk tə taɪni kɹæks dʊɹɪŋ sɪuənz tɛnjɝ əz æmɪɝlɪn. ɪf ʃid bɪn mɔɹ ʌv ə miɾieɪtɝ əmʌŋ ðə fækʃənz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, kəd ʃi hæv paʊndɪd stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪndə ðə boʊnz ə ðiz wɪmən? kəd ʃi hæv kɛpt əm fɹəm tɝnɪŋ ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝ laɪk ɹeɪzɝfɪʃ ɪn ə blʌd fɹɛnzi?

Elaida and her Ajah certainly bore the lionfish's share of the blame. But would the Tower have split in the first place if Siuan had fostered cooperation between the Ajahs? Elaida hadn't had that long to work. Every rift that appeared in the Tower could likely be traced back to tiny cracks during Siuan's tenure as Amyrlin. If she'd been more of a mediator among the factions of the White Tower, could she have pounded strength into the bones of these women? Could she have kept them from turning on one another like razorfish in a blood frenzy?

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. bʌɾ i wɑz oʊnli wʌn fɪɡjɝ ɪn ðə wivɪŋ ə ðiz faɪnəl deɪz.

The Dragon Reborn was important. But he was only one figure in the weaving of these final days.

ɪt wɑz tu izi tə fɝɡɛt ðæt, tu izi tə wɑtʃ ðə dʒɹəmæɾɪk fɪɡjɝ ə lɛdʒən ən fɝɡɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls.

It was too easy to forget that, too easy to watch the dramatic figure of legend and forget everyone else.

ʃi saɪd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp əɹ lɔnʒɹi ən - aʊɾ ə hæbət - tʃɛkɪŋ tə meɪk sɝɾən ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ðɛɹ. əz ʃi dɪd soʊ, ə fɪɡjɝ ɪn waɪɾ əpɹoʊtʃt əɹ fɹəm wʌn ə ðə bɹæntʃɪŋ pæθweɪz. "sɪuən sədaɪ?"

She sighed, picking up her laundry and - out of habit - checking to make certain everything was there. As she did so, a figure in white approached her from one of the branching pathways. "Siuan Sedai?"

sɪuən lʊkt ʌp, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ðə nɑvəs bɪfɔɹ əɹ wɑz wʌn ə ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɪst ɪn ðə kæmp. nɪɹli sɛvənti jɪɹz oʊld, ʃɛɝinə hæd ðə wɛðɝd, kɹis feɪs ʌv ə ɡɹændmʌðɝ. ʃi kɛpt əɹ sɪlvɝ hɛɹ ʌp ɪn ə bʌn, ən waɪl ʃi wɔkt wɪθaʊɾ ə stup, ðəɹ wɑz ə sɝɾən dɪstɪŋkt weɪt tə hɝ. ʃi hæd sin soʊ mʌtʃ, dʌn soʊ mʌtʃ, pæst soʊ mɛni jɪɹz. ən ənlaɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃɛɝinə hæd lɪvd ɔl ə ðoʊz jɪɹz. wɝkɪŋ, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə fæmli, ivən bɛɹiɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən.

Siuan looked up, frowning. The novice before her was one of the strangest in the camp. Nearly seventy years old, Sharina had the weathered, creased face of a grandmother. She kept her silver hair up in a bun, and while she walked without a stoop, there was a certain distinct weight to her. She had seen so much, done so much, passed so many years. And unlike an Aes Sedai, Sharina had lived all of those years. Working, raising a family, even burying children.

ʃi wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə paʊɝ. ɹɪmɑɹkəbli soʊ; ʃi wəd wɛɹ ðə ʃɔl fəɹ sɝɾən, ən əz sun əz ʃi dɪd, ʃid bi fɑɹ əbʌv sɪuən. fəɹ naʊ, ðoʊ, ʃɛɝinə kɝtsid dipli. ʃi ɡeɪv ən ɔlmoʊs pɝfəkt ʃoʊ ʌv dɛfɝəns. ʌv ɔl ə ðə nɑvəsɪz, ʃi wɑz noʊn tə kəmpleɪn ðə list, meɪk ðə lis tʃɹʌbəl, ən stʌɾi ðə moʊst əsɪdwəsli. əz ə nɑvəs, ʃi ʌndɝstʊd θɪŋz ðət moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɛvɝ lɝnd - əɹ hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðə moʊmən ðeɪ tʊk ðə ʃɔl. haʊ tə bi hʌmbəl wən nɛsəsɛɹi, haʊ tə teɪk ə pʌnɪʃmənt, haʊ tə noʊ wən jə niɾəd tə lɝn ɹæðɝ ðən pɹitɛn jə ɔlɹɛɾi nu. ɪf oʊnli wi hæɾ ə fju skɔɹ mɔɹ ə hɝ, sɪuən θɔt, ən ə fju skɔɹ lɛs ɪleɪɾəs ən ɹoʊmændəz.

She was strong in the power. Remarkably so; she would wear the shawl for certain, and as soon as she did, she'd be far above Siuan. For now, though, Sharina curtsied deeply. She gave an almost perfect show of deference. Of all of the novices, she was known to complain the least, make the least trouble, and study the most assiduously. As a novice, she understood things that most Aes Sedai had never learned - or had forgotten the moment they took the shawl. How to be humble when necessary, how to take a punishment, how to know when you needed to learn rather than pretend you already knew. If only we had a few score more of her, Siuan thought, and a few score less Elaidas and Romandas.

"jɛs, tʃaɪld?" sɪuən æskt. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

sɪuən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ wʊdnt wɑn jə tə taɪɝ jɝsɛlf."

The answer was obvious. The more threatened the women in the camp felt - the more danger they saw from Elaida - the easier it would be for a firm hand to seize control. The siege would never work, not now that the Aes Sedai inside it could Travel wherever and whenever they wished. Bryne's army at the bridges had become useless.

Siuan hesitated. Though Lelaine now played the part of Egwene's pious advocate, not too long ago she had been as displeased as everyone else over the too-old novices. Few liked it when traditions changed.

Hurry up, girl, Siuan thought to Egwene, glancing toward the spire of the White Tower. Sharina isn't the only one whose fate is entangled with yours. You've got us all wound up in that net of yours.
