CHAPTER 19

ɡæmbəts keɪɑs. ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld wɑz keɪɑs.

Gambits Chaos. The entire world was chaos.

tuɑn stʊɾ ɑn ðə bælkəni ʌv əɹ ɑɾiəns hɔl ɪn ðə pæləs ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ, hænz klæsp bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk. ɪn ðə pæləs ɡɹaʊnz - flæɡstoʊnz wɑʃt waɪt, laɪk soʊ mɛni sɝfəsəz ɪn ðə sɪɾi - ə ɡɹup ʌv ɔltɑɹən ɑɹmmɪn ɪn ɡoʊld ən blæk pɹæktəs fɔɹmeɪʃənz bɪniθ ðə wɑtʃfəl aɪz ʌv ə pɛɹ ə hɝ oʊn ɔfəsɝz. bɪɑn ðɛm, ðə sɪɾi pɹɑpɝ ɹoʊz, waɪt doʊmz bændɪd wɪð kʌlɝz spɹɛɾɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd tɔl, waɪt spaɪɹz.

Tuon stood on the balcony of her audience hall in the palace of Ebou Dar, hands clasped behind her back. In the palace grounds - flagstones washed white, like so many surfaces in the city - a group of Altaran armsmen in gold and black practiced formations beneath the watchful eyes of a pair of her own officers. Beyond them, the city proper rose, white domes banded with colors spreading alongside tall, white spires.

ɔɹɾɝ. hɪɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ðəɹ wɑz ɔɹɾɝ, ivən ɪn ðə filz ə tɛns ən wæɡənz aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi.

Order. Here in Ebou Dar, there was order, even in the fields of tents and wagons outside the city.

sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz pətʃɹoʊld ən kɛp ðə pis; ðəɹ wɝ plænz tə klin aʊt ðə ɹæhəd. dʒʌs kəz wʌn wɑz pʊɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə ɹizən - əɹ ən ɪkskjus - tə lɪv wɪθaʊt lɔ.

Seanchan soldiers patrolled and kept the peace; there were plans to clean out the Rahad. Just because one was poor was not a reason - or an excuse - to live without law.

bʌt ðɪs sɪɾi wɑz dʒʌst ə taɪni, taɪni pɑkəɾ ʌv ɔɹɾɝ ɪn ə wɝld ə tɛmpəst. sintʃæn ɪtsɛlf wɑz bɹoʊkən baɪ sɪvəl wɔɹ, naʊ ðət ði ɛmpɹɛs hæd daɪd. ðə kɔɝɪn hæd kʌm, bʌt ɹikæptʃɝɪŋ ðiz lænz ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ pɹəɡɹɛst sloʊli, stɔl baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn ði ist ən dəmɑni ɑɹmiz ɪn ðə nɔɹθ. ʃi stɪl weɪɾəd tə hɪɹ nuz ə lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl tʃɹən, bʌt ðə saɪnz wɝ nɑt ɡʊd. ɡælɡən meɪnteɪn ðət ðeɪ maɪt bi sɝpɹaɪzd ət ði aʊtkʌm, bʌt tuɑn hæd sin ə blæk dʌv ði aʊɝ ʃi wɑz ɪnfɔɹmd ə tʃɹənz pɹɪdɪkəmənt. ði oʊmən hæd bɪn klɪɹ. hi wəd nɑt ɹɪtɝn əlaɪv.

But this city was just a tiny, tiny pocket of order in a world of tempest. Seanchan itself was broken by civil war, now that the Empress had died. The Corenne had come, but recapturing these lands of Artur Hawkwing progressed slowly, stalled by the Dragon Reborn in the east and Domani armies in the north. She still waited to hear news of Lieutenant-General Turan, but the signs were not good. Galgan maintained that they might be surprised at the outcome, but Tuon had seen a black dove the hour she was informed of Turan's predicament. The omen had been clear. He would not return alive.

keɪɑs. ʃi ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd, wɛɹ feɪθfəl kɛɹid stʊɾ ɪn ɪz θɪk ɑɹmɝ, kʌlɝd blʌd-ɹɛɾ ən ə dip ɡɹin, nɪɹli blæk. hi wɑz ə tɔl mæn, skwɛɹ feɪs nɪɹli əz sɑləɾ əz ði ɑɹmɝ i wɔɹ.

Chaos. She glanced to the side, where faithful Karede stood in his thick armor, colored blood-red and a deep green, nearly black. He was a tall man, square face nearly as solid as the armor he wore.

hi hæd fʊli tu dʌzən dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz wɪð ɪm ðɪs deɪ - ðə deɪ æftɝ tuɑnz ɹɪtɝn tə ɛbu dɑɹ - əlɔŋ wɪð sɪks oʊɡiɝ ɡɑɹɾənɝz, ɔl stændɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz. ðeɪ laɪn ðə saɪdz ə ðə haɪ- silɪŋɡd, waɪt-pɪlɹd ɹum. kɛɹid sɛns ðə keɪɑs, ən dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə lɛɾ əɹ bi teɪkən əɡɛn.

He had fully two dozen Deathwatch Guards with him this day - the day after Tuon's return to Ebou Dar - along with six Ogier Gardeners, all standing along the walls. They lined the sides of the high- ceilinged, white-pillared room. Karede sensed the chaos, and did not intend to let her be taken again.

keɪɑs wɑz ðə moʊs dɛdli wən jə meɪɾ əsʌmpʃənz əbaʊt wʌɾ ɪt kəɾ ən kʊdn ɪnfɛkt. hɪɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ɪt mænəfɛstəɾ ɪn ðə fɔɹm ʌv ə fækʃən ɪntɛn ɑn teɪkɪŋ tuɑnz oʊn laɪf.

Chaos was the most deadly when you made assumptions about what it could and couldn't infect. Here in Ebou Dar, it manifested in the form of a faction intent on taking Tuon's own life.

ʃi hæd bɪn dɑdʒɪŋ əsæsəneɪʃənz sɪns ʃi kəd wɔk, ən ʃi hæd sɝvaɪvd əm ɔl. ʃi æntɪsəpeɪɾəd ðɛm. ɪn ə weɪ, ʃi θɹaɪv kəz ə ðɛm. haʊ wɝ jə tə noʊ ðət jə wɝ paʊɝfəl ənlɛs əsæsənz wɝ sɛn tə kɪl ju?

She had been dodging assassinations since she could walk, and she had survived them all. She anticipated them. In a way, she thrived because of them. How were you to know that you were powerful unless assassins were sent to kill you?

sjuɹɔθs bɪtʃɹeɪəl, haʊɛvɝ . . . keɪɑs, ɪndid, wən ðə liɾɝ ə ðə fɔɹʌnɝz hɝsɛlf tɝn tʃɹeɪɾɝ. bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə wɝl bæk ɪndə ɔɹɾɝ wɑz gɑnə bi vɛɹi, vɛɹi dɪfəkəlt. pɝhæps ɪmpɑsəbəl.

Suroth's betrayal, however . . . Chaos, indeed, when the leader of the Forerunners herself turned traitor. Bringing the world back into order was going to be very, very difficult. Perhaps impossible.

tuɑn stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ bæk. ʃi hæd nɑt θɔt tə bɪkʌm ɛmpɹɛs fəɹ mɛni jɪɹz jɛt. bʌt ʃi wəd də hɝ duɾi.

Tuon straightened her back. She had not thought to become Empress for many years yet. But she would do her duty.

ʃi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə bælkəni ən wɔk bæk ɪndə ði ɑɾiəns tʃeɪmbɝ tə feɪs ðə kɹaʊɾ əweɪɾɪŋ hɝ. laɪk ði ʌðɝz ə ðə blʌd, ʃi wɔɹ æʃəz ɑn əɹ tʃiks tə mɔɹn ðə lɔs ə ði ɛmpɹɛs. tuɑn hæd lɪɾəl əfɛkʃən fəɹ əɹ mʌðɝ, bʌɾ əfɛkʃən wɑz nɑt niɾəd fəɹ ən ɛmpɹɛs. ʃi pɹəvaɪɾəd ɔɹɾɝ ən stəbɪlɪɾi. tuɑn hæɾ oʊnli bɪɡʌn tə ʌndɝstæn ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə ðiz θɪŋz əz ðə weɪt hæd sɛɾəld ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz.

She turned away from the balcony and walked back into the audience chamber to face the crowd awaiting her. Like the others of the Blood, she wore ashes on her cheeks to mourn the loss of the Empress. Tuon had little affection for her mother, but affection was not needed for an empress. She provided order and stability. Tuon had only begun to understand the importance of these things as the weight had settled on her shoulders.

ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz waɪɾ ən ɹɛktæŋɡjəlɝ, lɪt wɪð kændələbɹəs bɪtwin ðə pɪlɝz ən ðə ɹeɪɾiənt ɡloʊ ʌv sʌnlaɪt θɹu ðə waɪd bælkəni bɪhaɪnd. tuɑn hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðə ɹumz ɹʌɡz ɹimuvd, pɹɪfɝɪŋ ðə bɹaɪt waɪt taɪlz. ðə silɪŋ bɔɹ ə peɪntəd mjʊɹəl ə fɪʃɝz ət si, wɪð ɡʌlz ɪn ðə klɪɹ ɛɹ, ən ðə wɔlz wɝ ə sɑf blu. ə ɡɹup ə tɛn dækoʊvæl nɛl bɪfɔɹ ðə kændələbɹəs tə tuɑnz ɹaɪt. ðeɪ wɔɹ fɪlmi kɑstumz, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə kəmænd. sjuɹɔθ wɑz nɑɾ əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd sɔ tə hɝ, ət list əntɪl əɹ hɛɹ ɡɹu aʊt.

The chamber was wide and rectangular, lit with candelabras between the pillars and the radiant glow of sunlight through the wide balcony behind. Tuon had ordered the room's rugs removed, preferring the bright white tiles. The ceiling bore a painted mural of fishers at sea, with gulls in the clear air, and the walls were a soft blue. A group of ten da'covale knelt before the candelabras to Tuon's right. They wore filmy costumes, waiting for a command. Suroth was not among them. The Deathwatch Guard saw to her, at least until her hair grew out.

əz sun əz tuɑn ɛntɝd ðə ɹum, ɔl ə ðə kɑmənɝz baʊɾ ɑn niz wɪð fɔɹhɛdz tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðoʊz ə ðə blʌd nɛlt, boʊɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz.

As soon as Tuon entered the room, all of the commoners bowed on knees with foreheads to the ground. Those of the Blood knelt, bowing their heads.

əkɹɔs fɹəm ðə dækoʊvæl, ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɔl, lənɛl ən mɛlɪtin nɛlt ɪn dʒɹɛsəz ɛmbleɪzənd wɪð sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls ɪn ɹɛd pænəlz ɑn ðɛɹ skɝts. ðɛɹ liʃt deɪmeɪn nɛl feɪsdaʊn. tuɑnz kɪdnæpɪŋ hæd bɪn ənbɛɹəbəl tə sɛvɹəl ə ðə deɪmeɪn; ðeɪ hæd teɪkən tə ɪnkənsələbəl wipɪŋ dʊɹɪŋ əɹ æbsəns.

Across from the da'covale, on the other side of the hall, Lanelle and Melitene knelt in dresses emblazoned with silver lightning bolts in red panels on their skirts. Their leashed damane knelt facedown. Tuon's kidnapping had been unbearable to several of the damane; they had taken to inconsolable weeping during her absence.

hɝ ɑɾiəns tʃɛɹ wɑz ɹɛləɾɪvli sɪmpəl. ə wʊɾən sit wɪð blæk vɛlvəɾ ɑn ði ɑɹmz ən bæk.

Her audience chair was relatively simple. A wooden seat with black velvet on the arms and back.

ʃi sæt daʊn, wɛɹɪŋ ə pliɾɪd ɡaʊn ə ðə dipəst si blu, ə waɪt keɪp flʌɾɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. əz sun əz ʃi dɪd, ðə pipəl ɪn ðə ɹum ɹoʊz fɹəm ðɛɹ pəzɪʃənz ʌv ædʒəleɪʃən - ɔl seɪv ðə dækoʊvæl, hu ɹɪmeɪnd nilɪŋ. sɪlutʃə stʊɾ ən stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɛɹ, hɝ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ɪn ə bɹeɪd daʊn əɹ ɹaɪt saɪd, ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə hɝ hɛd ʃeɪvən. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ði æʃəz, sɪns ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə ðə blʌd, bʌt ðə waɪt bæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət ʃi - laɪk ði ɪntaɪɝ ɛmpaɪɝ -  mɔɹn ðə lɔs ə ði ɛmpɹɛs.

She sat down, wearing a pleated gown of the deepest sea blue, a white cape fluttering behind her. As soon as she did, the people in the room rose from their positions of adulation - all save the da'covale, who remained kneeling. Selucia stood and stepped up beside the chair, her golden hair in a braid down her right side, the left side of her head shaven. She did not wear the ashes, since she was not of the Blood, but the white band on her arm indicated that she - like the entire Empire -  mourned the loss of the Empress.

jʊɹəl, tuɑnz sɛkɹətɛɹi ən sikɹɪtli hɝ hænd, stɛpt ʌp tə ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə tʃɛɹ. ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz muvd ɪn sʌɾəli ɝaʊn hɝ, dɑɹk ɑɹmɝ ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ feɪnli ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt. ðeɪ hæd bɪn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli pɹətɛktɪv ə hɝ leɪtli. ʃi dɪdn bleɪm ðɛm, ɹisən ɪvɛns kənsɪɾɝd.

Yuril, Tuon's secretary and secretly her Hand, stepped up to the other side of the chair. The Deathwatch Guards moved in subtly around her, dark armor glittering faintly in the sunlight. They had been particularly protective of her lately. She didn't blame them, recent events considered.

hɪɹ aɪ æm, tuɑn θɔt, sɝaʊndəd baɪ maɪ maɪt, deɪmeɪn ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ. ən jɛɾ aɪ fil noʊ seɪfɝ ðən aɪ dɪd wɪð meɪtʃɹim. haʊ ɑd, ðət ʃi ʃʊɾə fɛl seɪf wɪð hɪm.

Here I am, Tuon thought, surrounded by my might, damane on one side and Deathwatch Guard on the other. And yet I feel no safer than I did with Matrim. How odd, that she should have felt safe with him.

dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, lɪt baɪ ɪndɝɛk sʌnlaɪt fɹəm ði oʊpən bælkəni bɪhaɪnd, wɑz ə kəlɛkʃən ə ðə blʌd, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən haɪəst ə ðɛm. hi wɔɹ ɑɹmɝ ðɪs deɪ, ðə bɹɛstpleɪt peɪntəɾ ə dip blu, nɪɹli dɑɹk ɪnʌf tə bi blæk. hɪz paʊɾɝi waɪt hɛɹ ɹæn ɪn ə kɹɛst wɪð ðə saɪdz ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvən, ən wɑz pleɪɾəd tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, fəɹ i wɑz ə ðə haɪ blʌd. wɪð ɪm wɝ tu mɛmbɝz ə ðə loʊ blʌd - bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl nədʒɪɹə ən bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl jəmɑɾə - ən sɛvɹəl kɑmənɝ ɔfəsɝz. ðeɪ weɪɾəd peɪʃənli, kɛɹfəli nɑt miɾɪŋ tuɑnz aɪz.

Directly in front of her, lit by indirect sunlight from the open balcony behind, was a collection of the Blood, Captain-General Galgan highest of them. He wore armor this day, the breastplate painted a deep blue, nearly dark enough to be black. His powdery white hair ran in a crest with the sides of his head shaven, and was plaited to his shoulders, for he was of the High Blood. With him were two members of the low Blood - Banner-General Najirah and Banner-General Yamada - and several commoner officers. They waited patiently, carefully not meeting Tuon's eyes.

ə ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌv ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə ðə blʌd stʊd sɛvɹəl stɛps bɪhaɪnd, tə wɪtnəs əɹ æks. wɪɹi feɪvɹɾi nʌθɪʃ ən lɔŋ-feɪst əminɝ ʃumɑɾə lɛd ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ ɪmpɔɹɾənt - ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf tə bi deɪnʒɝəs. sjuɹɔθ wʊdn bi ði oʊnli wʌn u sɔ ɑpɝtunəɾi ɪn ðiz taɪmz. ɪf tuɑn wɝ tə fɔl, pɹæktəkli ɛniwʌn kəd bɪkʌm ɛmpɹɛs. əɹ ɛmpɝɝ.

A gathering of other members of the Blood stood several steps behind, to witness her acts. Wiry Faverde Nothish and long-faced Amenar Shumada led them. They were both important - important enough to be dangerous. Suroth wouldn't be the only one who saw opportunity in these times. If Tuon were to fall, practically anyone could become Empress. Or Emperor.

ðə wɔɹ ɪn sintʃæn wəd nɑɾ ɛn kwɪkli; bʌt wən ɪt dɪd, ðə vɪktɝ wəɾ əndaʊɾɪdli ɹeɪz hɪm- əɹ hɝsɛlf tə ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn əz wɛl. ən ðən ðəɹ wəd bi tu liɾɝz ə ðə sintʃæn ɛmpaɪɝ, dɪvaɪɾəd baɪ ən oʊʃən, junaɪɾəd ɪn dɪzaɪɝ tə kɑŋkɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ. niðɝ kəɾ əlaʊ ði ʌðɝ tə lɪv.

The war in Seanchan would not end quickly; but when it did, the victor would undoubtedly raise him- or herself to the Crystal Throne as well. And then there would be two leaders of the Seanchan Empire, divided by an ocean, united in desire to conquer one another. Neither could allow the other to live.

ɔɹɾɝ, tuɑn θɔt, tæpɪŋ ðə blæk wʊɾ ə hɝ ɑɹmɹɛst wɪð ə blu-lækɝd fɪŋɡɝneɪl.

Order, Tuon thought, tapping the black wood of her armrest with a blue-lacquered fingernail.

ɔɹɾɝ mʌst ɛməneɪt fɹəm mi. əl bɹɪŋ ðə kɑm ɛɹz tə ðoʊz bɪsɛt baɪ stɔɹmz.

Order must emanate from me. I will bring the calm airs to those beset by storms.

"sɪlutʃə ɪz maɪ tʃɹuθspikɝ," ʃi ənaʊns tə ðə ɹum. "lɛɾ ɪt bi pʌblɪʃt əmʌŋ ðə blʌd."

"Selucia is my Truthspeaker," she announced to the room. "Let it be published among the Blood."

ðə steɪtmənt wɑz ɪkspɛktəd. sɪlutʃə baʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn æksɛptəns, ðoʊ ʃi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ ɛni əpɔɪnmənt ʌðɝ ðən tə sɝv ən pɹətɛk tuɑn. ʃi wəd nɑt wɛlkəm ðɪs pəzɪʃən. bʌt ʃi wɑz ɔlsoʊ ɑnəst ən stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd; ʃi wəd meɪk ən ɛksələn tʃɹuθspikɝ.

The statement was expected. Selucia bowed her head in acceptance, though she had no desire for any appointment other than to serve and protect Tuon. She would not welcome this position. But she was also honest and straightforward; she would make an excellent Truthspeaker.

ət lis ðɪs taɪm, tuɑn kəd bi sɝɾən ðəɾ əɹ tʃɹuθspikɝ wɑznt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

At least this time, Tuon could be certain that her Truthspeaker wasn't one of the Forsaken.

dɪd ʃi bɪliv fælɛnʒɹz stɔɹi, ðɛn? ɪt stʃɹɛtʃt plɔzɪbɪlɪɾi; ɪt saʊndəd laɪk wʌn ə meɪtʃɹimz fænsɪfəl teɪlz ʌv ɪmædʒənɛɹi kɹitʃɝz ðət lɝkt ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ən jɛt, ði ʌðɝ sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn hæd kɝɑbɝeɪɾɪd fælɛnʒɹz teɪl.

Did she believe Falendre's story, then? It stretched plausibility; it sounded like one of Matrim's fanciful tales of imaginary creatures that lurked in the dark. And yet, the other sul'dam and damane had corroborated Falendre's tale.

səm fæks, ət list, sim stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd. ænæθ hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ wɪð sjuɹɔθ. sjuɹɔθ - æftɝ səm pɝsweɪʒən - hæɾ ədmɪɾəd ðət ʃi hæd mɛt wɪð wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ɔɹəɡən, ət list, ʃi θɔt ʃi hæd. ʃi hædnt noʊn ðət ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑz ðə seɪm əz ænæθ, bʌt ʃi sim tə faɪn ðə ɹɛvəleɪʃən bəlivəbəl.

Some facts, at least, seemed straightforward. Anath had been working with Suroth. Suroth - after some persuasion - had admitted that she had met with one of the Forsaken. Or, at least, she thought she had. She hadn't known that the Forsaken was the same as Anath, but she seemed to find the revelation believable.

wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi ɹɪli wɑz fɔɹseɪkən, ænæθ hæd mɛt wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ɪməteɪɾɪŋ tuɑn.

Whether or not she really was Forsaken, Anath had met with the Dragon Reborn, imitating Tuon.

ən hæd ðən tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm. ɔɹɾɝ, tuɑn θɔt, kipɪŋ əɹ feɪs stɪl. aɪ ɹɛpɹəzɛn ɔɹɾɝ.

And had then tried to kill him. Order, Tuon thought, keeping her face still. I represent order.

tuɑn dʒɛstʃɝd ɹæpədli tə sɪlutʃə, hu wɑz stɪl tuɑnz vɔɪs - ən əɹ ʃædoʊ - ivən wɪð ði æɾəd ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ʌv tʃɹuθspikɝ. wən ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðoʊz fɑɹ bɪniθ hɝsɛlf, tuɑn wəd fɝs pæs ðə wɝdz tə sɪlutʃə, hu wəd spik ðɛm.

Tuon gestured rapidly to Selucia, who was still Tuon's Voice - and her shadow - even with the added responsibility of Truthspeaker. When ordering those far beneath herself, Tuon would first pass the words to Selucia, who would speak them.

"ju ɑɹ ɹikwaɪɝd tə sɛn ɪm ɪn," sɪlutʃə sɛd tə ə dækoʊvæl bɪsaɪd ðə θɹoʊn. hi baʊd hɪmsɛlf tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, tʌtʃɪŋ hɛd tə ðə flɔɹ, ðən hɝid tə ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə lɑɹdʒ ɹum ən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

"You are required to send him in," Selucia said to a da'covale beside the throne. He bowed himself to the ground, touching head to the floor, then hurried to the other end of the large room and opened the door.

bɛslən, kɪŋ ʌv ɔltɑɹə ən haɪ siɾ ə haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹ, wɑz ə slɛndɝ juθ wɪð blæk aɪz ən hɛɹ. hi hæd ði ɑləv skɪn kɑmən tə ði ɔltɑɹən pipəl, bʌɾ i hæd teɪkən tə wɛɹɪŋ kloʊðɪŋ laɪk ðət feɪvɝd baɪ ðə blʌd. lus tʃɹaʊzɝz ə jɛloʊ ən ə haɪ-kɑlɝd koʊt ðət keɪm daʊn oʊnli tə ðə mɪɾəl ə hɪz tʃɛst, ə jɛloʊ ʃɝɾ ʌndɝniθ. ðə blʌd hæd lɛft ə klɪɹ pæsədʒ daʊn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum, ən bɛslən wɔk θɹu ɪt, aɪz loʊɝd. əpɑn ɹitʃɪŋ ðə sʌpləkeɪʃən speɪs bɪfɔɹ ðə θɹoʊn, hi wɛn daʊn ɑn ɪz niz, ðən baʊd loʊ. ðə pɝfəkt ɪmədʒ ʌv ə lɔɪəl sʌbʒɪkt, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə θɪn ɡoʊldən kɹaʊn ɑn ɪz hɛd.

Beslan, King of Altara and High Seat of House Mitsobar, was a slender youth with black eyes and hair. He had the olive skin common to the Altaran people, but he had taken to wearing clothing like that favored by the Blood. Loose trousers of yellow and a high-collared coat that came down only to the middle of his chest, a yellow shirt underneath. The Blood had left a clear passage down the middle of the room, and Beslan walked through it, eyes lowered. Upon reaching the supplication space before the throne, he went down on his knees, then bowed low. The perfect image of a loyal subject, except for the thin golden crown on his head.

tuɑn dʒɛstʃɝd tə sɪlutʃə.

Tuon gestured to Selucia.

"ju ɑɹ bɪɾən tə ɹaɪz," sɪlutʃə sɛd.

"You are bidden to rise," Selucia said.

bɛslən ɹoʊz, ðoʊ hi kɛpt ɪz ɡeɪz əvɝɾəd. hi wɑz ə faɪn æktɝ.

Beslan rose, though he kept his gaze averted. He was a fine actor.

"ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz ɪkspɹɛsəz əɹ kəndoʊlənsəz tə jə fəɹ jəɹ lɔs," sɪlutʃə sɛd tə hɪm.

"The Daughter of the Nine Moons expresses her condolences to you for your loss," Selucia said to him.

"aɪ ɡɪv ðə seɪm tə hɝ fəɹ əɹ lɔs," hi sɛd. "maɪ ɡɹif ɪz bʌɾ ə kændəl tə ðə ɡɹeɪt faɪɝ fɛl baɪ ðə sintʃæn pipəl."

"I give the same to her for her loss," he said. "My grief is but a candle to the great fire felt by the Seanchan people."

hi wɑz tu sɝvəl. hi wɑz ə kɪŋ; hi wɑz nɑt ɹikwaɪɝd tə baʊ hɪmsɛlf soʊ fɑɹ. hi wɑz ði ikwəl ə mɛni ʌv ðə blʌd.

He was too servile. He was a king; he was not required to bow himself so far. He was the equal of many of the Blood.

ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst əv bɪlivd i wɑz dʒʌs biɪŋ səbmɪsɪv bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən u wəd sun bɪkʌm ɛmpɹɛs. bʌt ʃi nu tu mʌtʃ ə hɪz tɛmpɹəmənt, θɹu boʊθ spaɪz ən hɪɹseɪ.

She could almost have believed he was just being submissive before the woman who would soon become Empress. But she knew too much of his temperament, through both spies and hearsay.

"ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz wɪʃɪz tə noʊ ðə ɹizən juv sis hoʊldɪŋ kɔɹt,"

"The Daughter of the Nine Moons wishes to know the reason you have ceased holding court,"

sɪlutʃə sɛd, wɑtʃɪŋ tuɑnz hænz muv. "ʃi faɪnz ɪt dɪstʃɹɛsɪŋ ðət jəɹ pipəl kænɑɾ əv ɑɾiəns wɪð ðɛɹ kɪŋ. jəɹ mʌðɝz dɛθ wɑz əz tʃɹædʒɪk əz ɪt wɑz ʃɑkɪŋ, bʌt jəɹ kɪŋdəm nidz ju."

Selucia said, watching Tuon's hands move. "She finds it distressing that your people cannot have audience with their king. Your mother's death was as tragic as it was shocking, but your kingdom needs you."

bɛslən baʊd. "pliz əv əɹ noʊ ðəɾ aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪɾ əpɹoʊpɹiət tə ɛləveɪt maɪsɛlf əbʌv hɝ. aɪm ənsɝɾən haʊ tə ækt. aɪ mɛnt noʊ ɪnsəlt."

Beslan bowed. "Please have her know that I did not think it appropriate to elevate myself above her. I am uncertain how to act. I meant no insult."

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən ðəɾ ɪz ðə tʃɹu ɹizən?" sɪlutʃə vɔɪst. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt, pɝhæps, kəz jə ɑɹ plænɪŋ ə ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛnst ʌs, ən də nɑɾ əv taɪm fəɹ jəɹ ʌðɝ duɾiz?"

"Are you certain that is the true reason?" Selucia Voiced. "It is not, perhaps, because you are planning a rebellion against us, and do not have time for your other duties?"

bɛslən lʊkt ʌp ʃɑɹpli, aɪz waɪd. "jɔɹ mædʒəsti, aɪ - "

Beslan looked up sharply, eyes wide. "Your Majesty, I - "

"ju nid nɑt spik ɛni fɝðɝ laɪz, tʃaɪld ə taɪlɪn," tuɑn sɛd dɝɛkli tə hɪm, kɑzɪŋ ɡæsps ə sɝpɹaɪz fɹəm ði əsɛmbəl blʌd. "aɪ noʊ ʌv ðə θɪŋz juv sɛd tə dʒɛnɝəl hæbɪɡɝ ən jəɹ fɹɛnd, lɔɹd meɪləlɪn. aɪ noʊ ʌv jəɹ kwaɪət miɾɪŋz ɪn ðə beɪsmən ə ðə θɹi stɑɹz. aɪ noʊ ʌv ɪɾ ɔl, kɪŋ bɛslən."

"You need not speak any further lies, child of Tylin," Tuon said directly to him, causing gasps of surprise from the assembled Blood. "I know of the things you have said to General Habiger and your friend, Lord Malalin. I know of your quiet meetings in the basement of The Three Stars. I know of it all, King Beslan."

ðə ɹum fɛl saɪlənt, bɛslən baʊɾ ɪz hɛd fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ðɛn, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, hi ɹoʊz tə hɪz fiɾ ən stɛɹɾ əɹ dɝɛkli ɪn ði aɪz. ʃi wʊdn əv θɔt ðə sɑft-spoʊkən juθ hæɾ ɪɾ ɪn hɪm. "aɪ wɪl nɑɾ əlaʊ maɪ pipəl tə - "

The room fell silent, Beslan bowed his head for a moment. Then, surprisingly, he rose to his feet and stared her directly in the eyes. She wouldn't have thought the soft-spoken youth had it in him. "I will not allow my people to - "

"aɪ wəd stɪl maɪ tʌŋ ɪf aɪ wɝ ju," tuɑn ɪntɝʌptɪd. "ju stæn ɑn sæn əz ɪɾ ɪz."

"I would still my tongue if I were you," Tuon interrupted. "You stand on sand as it is."

bɛslən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ʃi kəd si ðə kwɛstʃən ɪn ɪz aɪz. wɑznt ʃi gɑnə ɛksəkjut hɪm? ɪf aɪ ɪntɛndəd tə kɪl ju, ʃi θɔt, jə wəd bi dɛɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, ən jə wəd nɛvɝ əv sin ðə naɪf.

Beslan hesitated. She could see the question in his eyes. Wasn't she going to execute him? If I intended to kill you, she thought, you would be dead already, and you would never have seen the knife.

"sintʃæn ɪz ɪn əphivəl," tuɑn sɛd, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ hɪm. hi əpɪɹd ʃɑkt ət ðə wɝdz. "oʊ, dɪd jə θɪŋk aɪ wəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt, bɛslən? aɪm nɑt kɑntɛn tə stɛɹ ət ðə stɑɹz waɪl maɪ ɛmpaɪɝ kəlæpsɪz ɝaʊn mi. ðə tʃɹuθ mʌs bi æknɑlɪdʒd. maɪ mʌðɝ ɪz dɛd. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɛmpɹɛs.

"Seanchan is in upheaval," Tuon said, regarding him. He appeared shocked at the words. "Oh, did you think I would ignore it, Beslan? I am not content to stare at the stars while my empire collapses around me. The truth must be acknowledged. My mother is dead. There is no empress.

"haʊɛvɝ, ðə fɔɹsɪz ə ðə kɔɝɪn ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən səfɪʃən tə meɪnteɪn əɹ pəzɪʃənz hɪɹ ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən, ɔltɑɹə ɪnkluɾəd." ʃi lin fɔɹwɝd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹədʒɛkt ə sɛns ə kəntʃɹoʊl, ʌv fɝmnəs. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə də soʊ əɾ ɔl taɪmz. tuɑn dɪd nɑɾ əv əɹ mʌðɝz haɪt, bʌt ʃi wəd nid ðəɾ ɔɹə. ʌðɝz hæd tə fil seɪfɝ, mɔɹ sɪkjʊɹ, sɪmpli baɪ ɛntɝɪŋ əɹ pɹɛzəns.

"However, the forces of the Corenne are more than sufficient to maintain our positions here on this side of the ocean, Altara included." She leaned forward, trying to project a sense of control, of firmness. Her mother had been able to do so at all times. Tuon did not have her mother's height, but she would need that aura. Others had to feel safer, more secure, simply by entering her presence.

"ɪn taɪmz sətʃ əz ðiz," tuɑn kəntɪnjud, "θɹɛts ə ɹɪbɛljən kænɑt bi tɑlɝeɪɾəd. mɛni wɪl si ɑpɝtunəɾi ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝz wiknəs, ən ðɛɹ dɪvaɪsɪv skwɑbəlɪŋ - ɪf lɛft əntʃɛkt - wəd pɹuv ði ɛn ʌv əs ɔl. ðɛɹfɔɹ, aɪ mʌs bi fɝm. vɛɹi fɝm. wɪð ðoʊz u dɪfaɪ mi."

"In times such as these," Tuon continued, "threats of rebellion cannot be tolerated. Many will see opportunity in the Empire's weakness, and their divisive squabbling - if left unchecked - would prove the end of us all. Therefore, I must be firm. Very firm. With those who defy me."

"ðɛn waɪ," bɛslən sɛd, "æm aɪ stɪl əlaɪv?"

"Then why," Beslan said, "am I still alive?"

"ju stɑɹɾəd plænɪŋ jəɹ ɹɪbɛljən bɪfɔɹ ɪvɛns ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝ wɝ meɪd noʊn."

"You started planning your rebellion before events in the Empire were made known."

hi fɹaʊnd, dʌmfaʊndɪd.

He frowned, dumbfounded.

"ju bɪɡæn jəɹ ɹɪbɛljən wən sjuɹɔθ lɛd hɪɹ," tuɑn sɛd, "ænd wən jəɹ mʌðɝ wɑz stɪl kwin. mʌtʃ əz tʃeɪnʒd sɪns ðɛn, bɛslən. vɛɹi mʌtʃ. ɪn taɪmz laɪk ðiz, ðəɹ ɪz pətɛnʃəl fəɹ ɡɹeɪɾ əkɑmplɪʃmənt."

"You began your rebellion when Suroth led here," Tuon said, "and when your mother was still queen. Much has changed since then, Beslan. Very much. In times like these, there is potential for great accomplishment."

"ju mʌs noʊ aɪ hæv noʊ θɝs fəɹ paʊɝ," bɛslən sɛd. "ðə fɹiɾəm ə maɪ pipəl ɪz ɔl aɪ dɪzaɪɝ."

"You must know I have no thirst for power," Beslan said. "The freedom of my people is all I desire."

"aɪ də noʊ ɪt," tuɑn sɛd, klæspɪŋ əɹ hænz bɪfɔɹ hɝ, lækɝd neɪlz kɝlɪŋ, ɛlboʊz ɑn ði ɑɹmɹɛsts ə hɝ tʃɛɹ. "æn ðəɾ ɪz ði ʌðɝ ɹizən jə ɑɹ stɪl əlaɪv. jə ɹɛbəl nɑɾ aʊɾ ə lʌs fəɹ steɪʃən, bʌɾ aʊɾ ə ʃɪɹ ɪɡnɝəns. jə ɑɹ mɪsɡaɪɾɪd, ən ðət minz jə kən tʃeɪnʒ, ʃəd jə ɹəsiv ðə pɹɑpɝ nɑlədʒ."

"I do know it," Tuon said, clasping her hands before her, lacquered nails curling, elbows on the armrests of her chair. "And that is the other reason you are still alive. You rebel not out of lust for station, but out of sheer ignorance. You are misguided, and that means you can change, should you receive the proper knowledge."

hi lʊkt ət hɝ, kənfjuzd. loʊɝ jəɹ aɪz, ful. doʊn meɪk mi hæv jə stʃɹæp fəɹ ɪnsələns! əz ɪf i hæd hɝɾ əɹ θɔts, hi əvɝɾəd ɪz aɪz, ðən loʊɝd ðɛm. jɛs, ʃi hæd dʒʌdʒ kɝɛkli ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðɪs wʌn.

He looked at her, confused. Lower your eyes, fool. Don't make me have you strapped for insolence! As if he had heard her thoughts, he averted his eyes, then lowered them. Yes, she had judged correctly regarding this one.

haʊ pɹikɛɹiəs əɹ pəzɪʃən wɑz! tʃɹu, ʃi hæɾ ɑɹmiz - bʌt soʊ mɛni ʌv əm hæd bɪn θɹoʊn əweɪ baɪ sjuɹɔθs əɡɹɛʃən.

How precarious her position was! True, she had armies - but so many of them had been thrown away by Suroth's aggression.

ɔl kɪŋdəmz ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən wəd nid tə baʊ bɪfɔɹ ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, ɪvɛntʃəwəli.

All kingdoms on this side of the ocean would need to bow before the Crystal Throne, eventually.

itʃ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn wəd bi liʃt, itʃ kɪŋ əɹ kwin wəd swɛɹ ði oʊðz. bʌt sjuɹɔθ hæd pʊʃt tu hɑɹd, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪn ðə fiæskoʊ wɪð tʃɹən. ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən mɛn, lɔst ɪn wʌn bæɾəl.

Each marath'damane would be leashed, each king or queen would swear the oaths. But Suroth had pushed too hard, particularly in the fiasco with Turan. A hundred thousand men, lost in one battle.

mædnəs.

Madness.

tuɑn niɾəd ɔltɑɹə. ʃi niɾəd ɛbu dɑɹ. bɛslən wɑz wɛl lʌv baɪ ðə pipəl. pʊɾɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ə paɪk æftɝ ðə mɪstɪɹiəs dɛθ ə hɪz mʌðɝ. . . . wɛl, tuɑn wəɾ əv stəbɪlɪɾi ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, bʌt ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ nɑɾ əv tə liv bæɾəlfɹʌnts ənmæn tə əkɑmplɪʃ ɪt.

Tuon needed Altara. She needed Ebou Dar. Beslan was well loved by the people. Putting his head on a pike after the mysterious death of his mother. . . . Well, Tuon would have stability in Ebou Dar, but she would rather not have to leave battlefronts unmanned to accomplish it.

"jɔɹ mʌðɝz dɛθ ɪz ə lɔs," tuɑn sɛd. "ʃi wɑz ə ɡʊd wʊmən. ə ɡʊd kwin."

"Your mother's death is a loss," Tuon said. "She was a good woman. A good queen."

bɛslənz lɪps taɪɾənd.

Beslan's lips tightened.

"ju meɪ spik," tuɑn sɛd.

"You may speak," Tuon said.

"hɝ dɛθ . . . ɪz ʌnɪkspleɪnd," hi sɛd. ði ɪmpləkeɪʃən wɑz ɑbviəs.

"Her death . . . is unexplained," he said. The implication was obvious.

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ ɪf sjuɹɔθ kɑzd əɹ tə bi kɪld," tuɑn sɛd, sɔfənɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs. "ʃi kleɪmz ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt. bʌt ðə mæɾɝ ɪz biɪŋ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾəd. ɪf ɪt tɝnz aʊt ðət sjuɹɔθ wɑz bɪhaɪn ðə dɛθ, jə ən ɔltɑɹə wɪl əv ən əpɑlədʒi fɹəm ðə θɹoʊn ɪtsɛlf."

"I do not know if Suroth caused her to be killed," Tuon said, softening her voice. "She claims that she did not. But the matter is being investigated. If it turns out that Suroth was behind the death, you and Altara will have an apology from the throne itself."

ənʌðɝ ɡæsp fɹəm ðə blʌd. ʃi saɪlənst əm wɪð ə ɡlæns, ðən tɝn bæk tə bɛslən. "jɔɹ mʌðɝz lɔs ɪz ə ɡɹeɪt wʌn. jə mʌs noʊ ðət ʃi wɑz lɔɪəl tə hɝ oʊðz."

Another gasp from the Blood. She silenced them with a glance, then turned back to Beslan. "Your mother's loss is a great one. You must know that she was loyal to her oaths."

"jɛs," hi sɛd, vɔɪs bɪɾɝ. "ænd ʃi ɡeɪv ʌp ðə θɹoʊn."

"Yes," he said, voice bitter. "And she gave up the throne."

"noʊ," tuɑn sɛd kɝtli. "ðə θɹoʊn bɪlɔŋz tə ju. ðɪs ɪz ði ɪɡnɝəns ʌv wɪtʃ aɪ spoʊk. jə mʌs lɛd jəɹ pipəl. ðeɪ mʌst əv ə kɪŋ. aɪ hæv niðɝ taɪm nɔɹ dɪzaɪɝ tə də jəɹ duɾi fəɹ ju.

"No," Tuon said curtly. "The throne belongs to you. This is the ignorance of which I spoke. You must lead your people. They must have a king. I have neither time nor desire to do your duty for you.

"ju əsum ðət ðə sintʃæn dɑmənəns ə jəɹ hoʊmlænd wɪl min jəɹ pipəl læk fɹiɾəm.

"You assume that the Seanchan dominance of your homeland will mean your people lack freedom.

ðəɾ ɪz fɔls. ðəl bi mɔɹ fɹi, mɔɹ pɹətɛktəd, ən mɔɹ paʊɝfəl wən ðeɪ æksɛpt əɹ ɹul.

That is false. They will be more free, more protected, and more powerful when they accept our rule.

"aɪ sɪɾ əbʌv ju. bʌɾ ɪz ðɪs soʊ ʌndɪzaɪɹəbəl? wɪð ðə maɪɾ ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ, jəl bi eɪbəl tə hoʊl jəɹ bɔɹɾɝz ən pətʃɹoʊl jəɹ lænz aʊtsaɪɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ. jə spik ə jəɹ pipəl? wɛl, aɪ hæv ɔɹɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ju." ʃi nɑɾəd tə ðə saɪd, wɛɹ ə wɪləwi-lɪm dækoʊvæl stɛp fɔɹwɝd wɪð ə lɛðɝ sætʃəl.

"I sit above you. But is this so undesirable? With the might of the empire, you will be able to hold your borders and patrol your lands outside of Ebou Dar. You speak of your people? Well, I have ordered something prepared for you." She nodded to the side, where a willowy-limbed da'covale stepped forward with a leather satchel.

"ɪnsaɪd," tuɑn sɛd, "ju wɪl faɪnd nʌmbɝz ɡæðɝd baɪ maɪ skaʊts ən ɡɑɹd fɔɹsɪz. jə kən si dɝɛkli ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ə kɹaɪmz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ ɑkjəpeɪʃən hɪɹ. jəl əv ɹɪpɔɹts ən mænəfɛsts, kəmpɛɹɪŋ haʊ ðə pipəl wɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɪtɝn ən æftɝ ɪt.

"Inside," Tuon said, "you will find numbers gathered by my scouts and guard forces. You can see directly the reports of crimes during our occupation here. You will have reports and manifests, comparing how the people were before the Return and after it.

"aɪ bɪliv jə noʊ wʌt jəl faɪnd. ði ɛmpaɪɝ ɪz ə ɹisɔɹs tə ju, bɛslən. ə paʊɝfəl, paʊɝfəl ælaɪ. əl nɑɾ ɪnsʌl jə baɪ ɔfɝɪŋ jə θɹoʊnz jə də nɑt wɑnt. əl ɪntaɪs jə baɪ pɹɑməsɪŋ stəbɪlɪɾi, fud, ən pɹətɛkʃən fəɹ jəɹ pipəl. ɔl fəɹ ðə sɪmpəl pɹaɪs ə jəɹ lɔɪəlti."

"I believe you know what you will find. The Empire is a resource to you, Beslan. A powerful, powerful ally. I will not insult you by offering you thrones you do not want. I will entice you by promising stability, food, and protection for your people. All for the simple price of your loyalty."

hi hɛzɪɾəntli æksɛptɪd ðə sætʃəl.

He hesitantly accepted the satchel.

"aɪ ɔfɝ jə ə tʃɔɪs, bɛslən," tuɑn sɛd. "ju meɪ tʃuz ɛksəkjuʃən, ɪf jə wɪʃ. əl nɑt meɪk jə dækoʊvæl. əl lɛt jə daɪ wɪð ɑnɝ, ən ɪɾəl bi pʌblɪʃt ðət jə daɪd kəz jə ɹɪdʒɛktɪd ði oʊðz ən tʃoʊz nɑt tə æksɛp ðə sintʃæn. ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt, əl əlaʊ ɪt. jəɹ pipəl wɪl noʊ ðət jə daɪɾ ɪn dɪfaɪəns.

"I offer you a choice, Beslan," Tuon said. "You may choose execution, if you wish. I will not make you da'covale. I will let you die with honor, and it will be published that you died because you rejected the oaths and chose not to accept the Seanchan. If you wish it, I will allow it. Your people will know that you died in defiance.

"ɔɹ, jə meɪ tʃuz tə sɝv əm bɛɾɝ. jə meɪ tʃuz tə lɪv. ɪf jə də soʊ, jəl bi ɹeɪz tə ðə haɪ blʌd. jəl stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən ɹeɪn əz jəɹ pipəl nid jə tə du. aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðəɾ əl nɑt dɝɛk ði əfɛɹz ə jəɹ pipəl. əl dɪmæn ɹisɔɹsɪz ən mɛn fəɹ maɪ ɑɹmiz, əz ɪz pɹɑpɝ, ən jəɹ wɝd kænɑt kaʊntɝmən maɪ oʊn. əsaɪd fɹəm ðæt, jəɹ paʊɝ ɪn ɔltɑɹə wɪl bi æbsəlut. noʊ blʌd wɪl əv ðə ɹaɪt tə kəmænd, hɑɹm, əɹ ɪmpɹɪzən jəɹ pipəl wɪθaʊt jəɹ pɝmɪʃən.

"Or, you may choose to serve them better. You may choose to live. If you do so, you will be raised to the High Blood. You will step forward and reign as your people need you to do. I promise you that I will not direct the affairs of your people. I will demand resources and men for my armies, as is proper, and your word cannot countermand my own. Aside from that, your power in Altara will be absolute. No Blood will have the right to command, harm, or imprison your people without your permission.

"aɪ wɪl æksɛpt ən ɹivju ə lɪst ə noʊbəl fæmliz jə fil ʃəd bi ɹeɪz tə ðə loʊ blʌd, ən əl ɹeɪz noʊ fjuɝ ðən twɛnti ʌv ðɛm. ɔltɑɹə wɪl bɪkʌm ðə pɝmənən siɾ ə ði ɛmpɹɛs ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən. əz sʌtʃ, ɪɾəl bi ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl kɪŋdəm hɪɹ. jə meɪ tʃuz."

"I will accept and review a list of noble families you feel should be raised to the low Blood, and I will raise no fewer than twenty of them. Altara will become the permanent seat of the Empress on this side of the ocean. As such, it will be the most powerful kingdom here. You may choose."

ʃi lin fɔɹwɝd, ənleɪsɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. "bʌɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɪs. ɪf jə dɪsaɪd tə dʒɔɪn wɪð ʌs, jəl ɡɪmi jəɹ hɑɹt, ən nɑt dʒʌs jəɹ wɝdz. əl nɑɾ əlaʊ jə tə ɪɡnɔɹ jəɹ oʊðz. aɪ hæv ɡɪvən jə ðɪs tʃæns kəz aɪ bɪliv jə kən bi ə stʃɹɔŋ ælaɪ, ən aɪ θɪŋk ðət jə wɝ mɪsɡaɪɾɪd, pɝhæps baɪ sjuɹɔθs twɪstəd wɛbz.

She leaned forward, unlacing her fingers. "But understand this. If you decide to join with us, you will give me your heart, and not just your words. I will not allow you to ignore your oaths. I have given you this chance because I believe you can be a strong ally, and I think that you were misguided, perhaps by Suroth's twisted webs.

"ju hæv wʌn deɪ tə meɪk jəɹ dɪsɪʒən. θɪŋk wɛl. jəɹ mʌðɝ θɔt ðɪs tə bi ðə bɛs kɔɹs, ən ʃi wɑz ə waɪz wʊmən. ði ɛmpaɪɝ minz stəbɪlɪɾi. ə ɹɪbɛljən wəd min oʊnli sʌfɝɪŋ, stɑɹveɪʃən ən əbskjʊɹəɾi. ðiz ɑɹ nɑt taɪmz tə bi əloʊn, bɛslən."

"You have one day to make your decision. Think well. Your mother thought this to be the best course, and she was a wise woman. The Empire means stability. A rebellion would mean only suffering, starvation and obscurity. These are not times to be alone, Beslan."

ʃi sæt bæk əz bɛslən ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə sætʃəl ɪn ɪz hænz. hi baʊɾ ɪn sʌpləkeɪʃən tə wɪðdʒɹɔ, ðoʊ ðə moʊʃən wɑz dʒɝki, əz ɪf i wɝ dɪstʃɹæktəd.

She sat back as Beslan regarded the satchel in his hands. He bowed in supplication to withdraw, though the motion was jerky, as if he were distracted.

"ju meɪ ɡoʊ," ʃi sɛd tə hɪm.

"You may go," she said to him.

hi ɹoʊz, bʌt dɪd nɑt tɝn tə liv. ðə ɹum fɛl stɪl əz i stɛɹd daʊn əɾ ɪz hænz ən ðə sætʃəl. ʃi kəd ɹiɾ ɪz stʃɹʌɡəl ɪn ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən. ə dækoʊvæl əpɹoʊtʃt tə heɪsən ɪm ɑn ɪz weɪ, əz i hæd bɪn dɪsmɪst, bʌt tuɑn ɹeɪzd əɹ hænd, stɪlɪŋ ðə sɝvənt.

He rose, but did not turn to leave. The room fell still as he stared down at his hands and the satchel. She could read his struggle in his expression. A da'covale approached to hasten him on his way, as he had been dismissed, but Tuon raised her hand, stilling the servant.

ʃi lin fɔɹwɝd, sɛvɹəl mɛmbɝz ə ðə blʌd ʃʌflɪŋ ðɛɹ fiɾ əz ðeɪ weɪɾəd. bɛslən dʒʌst stɛɹɾ ət ðət sætʃəl. faɪnəli, hi lʊkt ʌp, aɪz dɪtɝmənd. ən ðɛn, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, hi ɡɑt bæk daʊn ɑn ɪz niz.

She leaned forward, several members of the Blood shuffling their feet as they waited. Beslan just stared at that satchel. Finally, he looked up, eyes determined. And then, surprisingly, he got back down on his knees.

"aɪ, bɛslən ə haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹ, plɛdʒ maɪ fiəlti ən sɝvəs tə ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz ən θɹu hɝ tə ðə sintʃæn ɛmpaɪɝ, naʊ ən fəɹ ɔl taɪm, seɪv ðət ʃi tʃuzəz tə ɹilis mi ʌv əɹ oʊn wɪl. maɪ lænz ən θɹoʊn ɑɹ hɝz, ən aɪ jild əm tə hɝ hænd. soʊ aɪ də swɛɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪt."

"I, Beslan of House Mitsobar, pledge my fealty and service to the Daughter of the Nine Moons and through her to the Seanchan Empire, now and for all time, save that she chooses to release me of her own will. My lands and throne are hers, and I yield them to her hand. So I do swear before the Light."

tuɑn lɛt hɝsɛlf smaɪl. bɪhaɪn bɛslən, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ðə kɪŋ. "ðæɾ ɪz nɑt ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪ tə - "

Tuon let herself smile. Behind Beslan, Captain-General Galgan stepped forward, addressing the King. "That is not the proper way to - "

tuɑn saɪlənst ɪm wɪð ə dʒɛstʃɝ. "wi dɪmæn ðət ðɪs pipəl ədɑpt əɹ weɪz, dʒɛnɝəl," ʃi sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz fɪɾɪŋ ðət wi æksɛp səm ə ðɛɹz." nɑt tu mɛni ʌv ðoʊz weɪz, ʌv kɔɹs. bʌt ʃi kəd θæŋk əɹ lɔŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃənz wɪð mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən fəɹ əlaʊɪŋ əɹ tə ʌndɝstæn ðɪs. ðə sintʃæn hæd, pɝhæps, meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk wɪð ðɪs pipəl ɪn meɪkɪŋ əm swɛɹ sintʃæn oʊðz ʌv oʊbiɾiəns. meɪtʃɹim hæd swɔɹn ðoʊz oʊðz, bʌɾ ɪɡnɔɹɾ əm hændəli wən ðə taɪm keɪm - jɛɾ i hæd bɪn sɝɾən tə kip ɪz wɝd tə hɝ, ən ɪz mɛn hæɾ əʃʊɹɾ əɹ i wɑz ə mæn ʌv ɑnɝ.

Tuon silenced him with a gesture. "We demand that this people adopt our ways, General," she said. "It is fitting that we accept some of theirs." Not too many of those ways, of course. But she could thank her long conversations with Mistress Anan for allowing her to understand this. The Seanchan had, perhaps, made a mistake with this people in making them swear Seanchan oaths of obedience. Matrim had sworn those oaths, but ignored them handily when the time came - yet he had been certain to keep his word to her, and his men had assured her he was a man of honor.

haʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət ðeɪ wəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə ɛləveɪt wʌn oʊθ oʊvɝ ənʌðɝ. ðiz pipəl wɝ ɑd.

How strange that they would be willing to elevate one oath over another. These people were odd.

bʌt ʃi wəɾ əv tə ʌndɝstæn əm ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹul əm - ən ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɹul əm tə ɡæðɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ fəɹ əɹ ɹɪtɝn tə sintʃæn.

But she would have to understand them in order to rule them - and she would have to rule them to gather strength for her return to Seanchan.

"jɔɹ oʊθ ɪz plizɪŋ tə mi, kɪŋ bɛslən. aɪ ɹeɪz jə tə ðə haɪ blʌɾ ən ɡɪv jə ən jəɹ haʊs dɑmənəns oʊvɝ ðə kɪŋdəm ʌv ɔltɑɹə, fəɹ naʊ ən ɔl taɪm, jəɹ wɪl fəɹ ði ædmɪnɪstʃɹeɪʃən ən ɡʌvɝnəns ʌv ɪt sɛkən oʊnli tə ðəɾ ə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl θɹoʊn ɪtsɛlf. ɹaɪz."

"Your oath is pleasing to me, King Beslan. I raise you to the High Blood and give you and your House dominance over the kingdom of Altara, for now and all time, your will for the administration and governance of it second only to that of the Imperial Throne itself. Rise."

hi stʊd, lɛɡz lʊkɪŋ ʃeɪki. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jəɹ nɑt tɑvɝən, maɪ leɪɾi?" hi æskt.

He stood, legs looking shaky. "Are you certain you're not ta'veren, my Lady?" he asked.

"bɪkɔz aɪ sɝɾənli wɑzn ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə də ðət wən aɪ wɔkt ɪn hɪɹ."

"Because I certainly wasn't expecting to do that when I walked in here."

tɑvɝən. ðiz pipəl ən ðɛɹ fulɪʃ supɝstɪʃənz! "aɪ æm plizd wɪð ju," ʃi sɛd tə hɪm.

Ta'veren. These people and their foolish superstitions! "I am pleased with you," she said to him.

"aɪ nu jəɹ mʌðɝ fəɹ oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt taɪm, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd faɪn əɹ kwaɪt keɪpəbəl. aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv ɛndʒɔɪd biɪŋ fɔɹs tə ɛksəkjuɾ əɹ oʊnli ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ sʌn."

"I knew your mother for only a short time, but I did find her quite capable. I would not have enjoyed being forced to execute her only remaining son."

hi nɑɾəd ɪn əpɹiʃieɪʃən. tə ðə saɪd, sɪlutʃə kʌvɝtli saɪnd, ðət wɑz wɛl hændəld.

He nodded in appreciation. To the side, Selucia covertly signed, That was well handled.

ʌnkənvɛnʃənəl, pɝhæps, bʌt vɛɹi dɛləkətli dʌn.

Unconventional, perhaps, but very delicately done.

tuɑn fɛlt ə wɔɹm sɛns ə pɹaɪd. ʃi tɝn tə ðə waɪt-hɛɹd dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən. "dʒɛnɝəl. aɪ ɹilaɪz juv bɪn weɪɾɪŋ tə spik wɪð mi, ən jəɹ peɪʃəns ɪz tə bi kəmɛndɪd. jə meɪ naʊ spik jəɹ θɔts. kɪŋ bɛslən, jə meɪ wɪðdʒɹɔ əɹ ɹɪmeɪn. ɪts jəɹ ɹaɪt tə ətɛn ɛni pʌblɪk kɑnfɝənsəz aɪ hæv ɪn jəɹ kɪŋdəm, ən jə nid noʊ pɝmɪʃən əɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃən tə ətɛnd."

Tuon felt a warm sense of pride. She turned to the white-haired General Galgan. "General. I realize you have been waiting to speak with me, and your patience is to be commended. You may now speak your thoughts. King Beslan, you may withdraw or remain. It is your right to attend any public conferences I have in your kingdom, and you need no permission or invitation to attend."

bɛslən nɑɾəd, boʊɪŋ bʌt ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum tə wɑtʃ.

Beslan nodded, bowing but retreating to the side of the room to watch.

"θæŋk ju, haɪəs dɔɾɝ," ɡælɡən sɛd ɹɛvɝənli, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. hi weɪv tə hɪz sɔɪhɪn, hu stʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd. ðeɪ ɛntɝd - fɝs pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz bɪfɔɹ tuɑn -  ðən kwɪkli sɛɾ ʌp ə teɪbəl ən sɛvɹəl mæps. wʌn sɝvən bɹɔt ɡælɡən ə bʌndəl, wɪtʃ i kæɹid, əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ tuɑn. kɛɹid wɑz əɾ əɹ ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ ɪn ə moʊmənt, sɪlutʃə əɾ əɹ lɛft, bʌt ɡælɡən kɛpt ə ɹɪspɛkfəl dɪstəns. hi baʊɾ ən ənɹoʊl ði aɪɾəm ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɪt wɑz ə bænɝ ə ɹɛd, bɛɹɪŋ ə sɝkəl ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, splɪt baɪ ə sɪnwəs laɪn. wʌn hæf ə ðə sɝkəl wɑz blæk, ði ʌðɝ waɪt.

"Thank you, Highest Daughter," Galgan said reverently, stepping forward. He waved to his so'jhin, who stood in the hallway outside. They entered - first prostrating themselves before Tuon -  then quickly set up a table and several maps. One servant brought Galgan a bundle, which he carried, approaching Tuon. Karede was at her right shoulder in a moment, Selucia at her left, but Galgan kept a respectful distance. He bowed and unrolled the item on the ground. It was a banner of red, bearing a circle in the center, split by a sinuous line. One half of the circle was black, the other white.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" tuɑn æskt, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd.

"What is it?" Tuon asked, leaning forward.

"ðə bænɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ɡælɡən sɛd. "hi sɛn ɪt wɪð ə mɛsənʒɝ, æskɪŋ jɛɾ əɡɛn fəɹ ə miɾɪŋ." hi ɡlænst ʌp - nɑt miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz, bʌt ʃoʊɪŋ ə θɔtfəl, kənsɝn feɪs.

"The banner of the Dragon Reborn," Galgan said. "He sent it with a messenger, asking yet again for a meeting." He glanced up - not meeting her eyes, but showing a thoughtful, concerned face.

"ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ wən aɪ ɝoʊz," tuɑn sɛd, "aɪ sɔ ə pæɾɝn laɪk θɹi taʊɝz ɪn ðə skaɪ ən ə hɔk, haɪ ɪn ði ɛɹ, pæsɪŋ bɪtwin ðɛm."

"This morning when I arose," Tuon said, "I saw a pattern like three towers in the sky and a hawk, high in the air, passing between them."

ðə vɛɹiəs mɛmbɝz ə ðə blʌɾ ɪn ðə ɹum nɑɾəd əpɹiʃieɪɾɪvli. oʊnli bɛslən sim kənfjuzd. haʊ dɪd ðiz pipəl laɪv, nɑt noʊɪŋ ði oʊmənz? hæd ðeɪ noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə ʌndɝstæn ðə vɪʒənz ə feɪt ðə pæɾɝn wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ ðɛm? ðə hɔk ən θɹi taʊɝz wɝ ən oʊmən ə dɪfəkəl tʃɔɪsəz tə kʌm. ðeɪ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət boʊlnəs wəd bi niɾəd.

The various members of the Blood in the room nodded appreciatively. Only Beslan seemed confused. How did these people live, not knowing the omens? Had they no desire to understand the visions of fate the Pattern was giving them? The hawk and three towers were an omen of difficult choices to come. They indicated that boldness would be needed.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jəɹ θɔts ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹnz ɹɪkwɛs fəɹ ə miɾɪŋ?" tuɑn æskt ɡælɡən.

"What are your thoughts on the Dragon Reborn's request for a meeting?" Tuon asked Galgan.

"pɝhæps ɪt wəd bi ənwaɪz tə mit wɪð ðɪs mæn, haɪəs dɔɾɝ. aɪm nɑt sɝɾən ə hɪz kleɪmz tə hɪz taɪɾəl. bɪɑn ðɪs kwɛstʃən, dʌz ði ɛmpaɪɝ nɑɾ əv ʌðɝ kənsɝnz ət ðɪs taɪm?"

"Perhaps it would be unwise to meet with this man, Highest Daughter. I am not certain of his claims to his title. Beyond this question, does the Empire not have other concerns at this time?"

"ju wʌndɝ waɪ əɹ fɔɹsɪz əv nɑt ɹitʃɹiɾəd," tuɑn sɛd. "waɪ wɪv nɑt stʃɹʌk aʊt fəɹ sintʃæn tə sɪkjʊɹ ðə θɹoʊn."

"You wonder why our forces have not retreated," Tuon said. "Why we have not struck out for Seanchan to secure the throne."

hi baʊɾ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ tʃɹʌs jəɹ wɪzdəm, haɪəs dɔɾɝ."

He bowed his head. "I trust your wisdom, Highest Daughter."

"ðɪs ɪz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," tuɑn sɛd. "ænd nɑt dʒʌst ən ɪmpɔstɝ. aɪm kənvɪnst ʌv ɪt. hi mʌs baʊ bɪfɔɹ ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl kən bɪɡɪn. ən soʊ wi mʌst steɪ. ɪts nɑɾ ən æksəɾənt ðət ðə ɹɪtɝn hæpənd naʊ. wəɹ niɾəd hɪɹ. mɔɹ ðən wəɹ niɾəd, ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ɪn əɹ hoʊmlænd."

"This is the Dragon Reborn," Tuon said. "And not just an impostor. I am convinced of it. He must bow before the Crystal Throne before the Last Battle can begin. And so we must stay. It is not an accident that the Return happened now. We are needed here. More than we are needed, unfortunately, in our homeland."

ɡælɡən nɑɾəd sloʊli. hi əɡɹid wɪð əɹ ɑn nɑt ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ tə sintʃæn; hi hæd sɪmpli əsumd ɪt wəd bi wʌt ʃi wɪʃt. ɪn dɪklɛɹɪŋ ðeɪ wəd steɪ, ʃi hæɾ ɝn ɪz ɹɪspɛkt. nɑt ðəɾ i wʊdn stɪl kənsɪɾɝ sizɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. ə mæn kəd nɑt hoʊld ɪz pəzɪʃən wɪθaʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv æmbɪʃən.

Galgan nodded slowly. He agreed with her on not retreating to Seanchan; he had simply assumed it would be what she wished. In declaring they would stay, she had earned his respect. Not that he wouldn't still consider seizing the throne for himself. A man could not hold his position without a great deal of ambition.

haʊɛvɝ, hi wɑz noʊn tə bi ə pɹuɾənt mæn əz wɛl əz ən æmbɪʃəs wʌn. hi wəd nɑt stʃɹaɪk ənlɛs i wɑz kənvɪnst ɪt wɑz fəɹ ðə bɛst. hi wəɾ əv tə bɪliv ðəɾ i hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ pətɛnʃəl fəɹ səksɛs ən ðət ɹimuvɪŋ tuɑn wəd bi bɛɾɝ fəɹ ði ɛmpaɪɝ. ðət wɑz ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ən æmbɪʃəs ful ən ən æmbɪʃəs waɪz mæn. ðə læɾɝ ʌndɝstʊd ðət kɪlɪŋ sʌmwʌn wɑz oʊnli ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. teɪkɪŋ tuɑnz laɪf ən əsumɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn hɪmsɛlf wəd ɡeɪn ɪm nʌθɪŋ ɪf ɪɾ eɪliəneɪɾəd ðə ɹɛst ə ðə blʌd.

However, he was known to be a prudent man as well as an ambitious one. He would not strike unless he was convinced it was for the best. He would have to believe that he had a strong potential for success and that removing Tuon would be better for the Empire. That was the difference between an ambitious fool and an ambitious wise man. The latter understood that killing someone was only the beginning. Taking Tuon's life and assuming the throne himself would gain him nothing if it alienated the rest of the Blood.

hi wɔk tə hɪz teɪbəl wɪð mæps. "ɪf jə wɪʃ tə kəntɪnju tə pɹɑsəkjut ðə wɔɹ, haɪəs dɔɾɝ, pɝmɪt mi tə ɪkspleɪn ðə kəndɪʃən ə jəɹ ɑɹmi. wʌn ʌv əɹ moʊst æmbɪʃəs plænz ɪz biɪŋ ɔɹɡənaɪz baɪ lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl julən."

He walked to his table with maps. "If you wish to continue to prosecute the war, Highest Daughter, permit me to explain the condition of your army. One of our most ambitious plans is being organized by Lieutenant-General Yulan."

ɡælɡən dʒɛstʃɝd tə ði əsɛmbəld ɔfəsɝz ən ə ʃɔɹt, dɑɹk-skɪn mæn ə ðə loʊ blʌd stɛp fɔɹwɝd. hi wɔɹ ə blæk wɪɡ tə haɪɾ ɪz bɔlnəs, ən i əpɹoʊtʃt ən nɛl bɪfɔɹ tuɑn, boʊɪŋ.

Galgan gestured to the assembled officers and a short, dark-skinned man of the low Blood stepped forward. He wore a black wig to hide his baldness, and he approached and knelt before Tuon, bowing.

"ju ɑɹ kəmændəd tə ɹaɪz ən spik, dʒɛnɝəl," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst.

"You are commanded to rise and speak, General," Selucia Voiced.

"ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ ʃəd noʊ maɪ θæŋks," julən sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. ət ðə mæp teɪbəl, hi dʒɛstʃɝd fəɹ sɛvɹəl eɪdz tə hoʊld ʌp ə mæp soʊ ðət tuɑn kəd si. "əsaɪd fɹəm sɛtbæks ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, ðə pɹɑsɛs ə ɹikleɪmɪŋ ðiz lænz əz pɹəsiɾəd əz ɪkspɛktəd. mɔɹ sloʊli ðən wi wəd wɪʃ, bʌt nɑt wɪθaʊt ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝiz. ðə pipəl ə ðiz kɪŋdəmz də nɑt ɹæli tə ðə dɪfɛns ə ðɛɹ neɪbɝɪŋ neɪʃənz. wɪv hæd ɡɹeɪt səksɛs sizɪŋ əm wʌn əɾ ə taɪm. oʊnli tu ɪʃuz kɑz əs wɝi. ðə fɝst ɪz ðɪs ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, hu hæz bɪn pɝsuɪŋ ən əɡɹɛsɪv wɔɹ ə junəfəkeɪʃən tə ðə nɔɹθ ən ist. ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝz wɪzdəm wɪl bi niɾəd ɪn titʃɪŋ əs tə səbdu hɪm.

"The Highest Daughter should know my thanks," Yulan said, rising. At the map table, he gestured for several aides to hold up a map so that Tuon could see. "Aside from setbacks in Arad Doman, the process of reclaiming these lands has proceeded as expected. More slowly than we would wish, but not without great victories. The people of these kingdoms do not rally to the defense of their neighboring nations. We have had great success seizing them one at a time. Only two issues cause us worry. The first is this Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn, who has been pursuing an aggressive war of unification to the north and east. The Highest Daughter's wisdom will be needed in teaching us to subdue him.

"ði ʌðɝ kənsɝn əz bɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɪn ðə pleɪs noʊn əz tɑɹ vəlɑn. aɪ bɪliv ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ əz hɝɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt wɛpən ðeɪ juz tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ə lɑɹdʒ pætʃ ə lænd nɔɹθ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ."

"The other concern has been the large number of marath'damane concentrated in the place known as Tar Valon. I believe the Highest Daughter has heard of the great weapon they used to destroy a large patch of land north of Ebou Dar."

tuɑn nɑɾəd.

Tuon nodded.

"ðə sʌldəm əv nɛvɝ sin ɪts laɪk," julən kəntɪnjud. "wi əsum ɪts ə θɪŋ ə deɪmeɪn, wɪtʃ kən bi tɔt tə ðɛm, ɪf ðə ɹaɪt mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɑɹ teɪkən. ðɪs wʌnʒɹəs əbɪləɾi ðeɪv tə tʃɹænspɔɹɾ ɪnstənli fɹəm wʌn pleɪs tə ənʌðɝ - ɪf tʃɹu - wɪl pɹuv ə sɛkən tɛknik ʌv ɡɹeɪt tæktɪkəl ædvæntɪdʒ ðət wi mʌs kæptʃɝ."

"The sul'dam have never seen its like," Yulan continued. "We assume it is a thing of damane, which can be taught to them, if the right marath'damane are taken. This wondrous ability they have to transport instantly from one place to another - if true - will prove a second technique of great tactical advantage that we must capture."

tuɑn nɑɾəd əɡɛn, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə mæp, wɪtʃ ʃoʊd ðə pleɪs kɔl tɑɹ vəlɑn. sɪlutʃə vɔɪst, "ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ ɪz kjʊɹiəs əz tə jəɹ plænz. jəl pɹəsid."

Tuon nodded again, studying the map, which showed the place called Tar Valon. Selucia Voiced, "The Highest Daughter is curious as to your plans. You will proceed."

"maɪ θæŋks ɑɹ ɪkspɹɛs dipli," julən sɛd, boʊɪŋ. "æz kæptən ə ði ɛɹ, aɪ hæv ði ɑnɝ ə kəmændɪŋ ðə ɹeɪkən ən tɔɹeɪkən sɝvɪŋ ðə ɹɪtɝn. aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ ə stʃɹaɪk ət ðə vɛɹi hɑɹɾ ʌv əɹ ɛnəmiz lænz wəd nɑɾ oʊnli bi pɑsəbəl, bʌt haɪli ædvənteɪdʒəs. wɪv nɑt jɛt hæd tə faɪt mɛni ʌv ðiz mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɪn kɑmbæt, bʌɾ əz wi ədvæns ɪndə lænz kəntʃɹoʊl baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, wɪl əndaʊɾɪdli feɪs əm ɪn ɡɹeɪt nʌmbɝz.

"My thanks are expressed deeply," Yulan said, bowing. "As Captain of the Air, I have the honor of commanding the raken and to'raken serving the Return. I believe that a strike at the very heart of our enemy's lands would not only be possible, but highly advantageous. We have not yet had to fight many of these marath'damane in combat, but as we advance into lands controlled by the Dragon Reborn, we will undoubtedly face them in great numbers.

"ðeɪ əsum ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ seɪf fɹəm əs ət ðɪs taɪm. ə stʃɹaɪk naʊ kəɾ əv ɡɹeɪɾ ɪmpækt ɑn ðə fjutʃɝ. itʃ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn wi liʃ ɪz nɑɾ oʊnli ə paʊɝfəl tul ɡeɪn baɪ əɹ fɔɹsɪz, bʌt wʌn lɔs baɪ ði ɛnəmi. pɹɪlɪmənɛɹi ɹɪpɔɹts kleɪm ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ hʌnʒɹədz əpɑn hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn kɑŋɡɹɪɡeɪɾɪd ɪn ðɪs pleɪs kɔl ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"They assume that they are safe from us at this time. A strike now could have great impact on the future. Each marath'damane we leash is not only a powerful tool gained by our forces, but one lost by the enemy. Preliminary reports claim that there are hundreds upon hundreds of marath'damane congregated in this place called the White Tower."

ðət mɛni? tuɑn θɔt. ə fɔɹs laɪk ðət kəd tɝn ðə wɔɹ ɪntaɪɝli. tʃɹu, ðoʊz mɛɹəθdəmeɪn u hæd tʃɹævəld wɪð meɪtʃɹim hæd sɛd ðət ðeɪ wəd nɑt teɪk pɑɹɾ ɪn wɔɹz. ɪndid, mɛɹəθdəmeɪn u hæd wʌns bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd - soʊ fɑɹ - pɹuvən jusləs əz wɛpənz. bʌt kəd ðəɹ bi səm weɪ tə twɪs ðɛɹ səpoʊz vaʊz? sʌmθɪŋ meɪtʃɹim hæd sɛɾ ɪn pæsɪŋ meɪɾ əɹ səspɛk ðeɪ kʊd. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz flu.

That many? Tuon thought. A force like that could turn the war entirely. True, those marath'damane who had traveled with Matrim had said that they would not take part in wars. Indeed, marath'damane who had once been Aes Sedai had - so far - proven useless as weapons. But could there be some way to twist their supposed vows? Something Matrim had said in passing made her suspect they could. Her fingers flew.

"ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz wʌndɝz haʊ ə stʃɹaɪk əɡɛnst əm kəd bi fizəbəl," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst. "ðə dɪstəns ɪz ɡɹeɪt. hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz."

"The Daughter of the Nine Moons wonders how a strike against them could be feasible," Selucia Voiced. "The distance is great. Hundreds of leagues."

"wi wəd juz ə fɔɹs ə moʊsli tɔɹeɪkən," dʒɛnɝəl julən sɛd. "wɪð səm ɹeɪkən fəɹ skaʊɾɪŋ.

"We would use a force of mostly to'raken," General Yulan said. "With some raken for scouting.

əɹ kæptʃɝd mæps ʃoʊ lɑɹdʒ ɡɹæslænz wɪð vɛɹi fju ɪnhæbəɾənts, wɪtʃ kəd bi juzd əz ɹɛstɪŋ pɔɪns əlɔŋ ðə weɪ. wi kəd stʃɹaɪk əkɹɔs mʊɹændi hɪɹ," hi pɔɪntəɾ əɾ ə sɛkən mæp, wɪtʃ eɪdz hɛld ʌp, "æn kʌm ət tɑɹ vəlɑn fɹəm ðə saʊθ. ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ, wi kəd ɹeɪɾ ət naɪt, waɪl ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɑɹ əslip. əɹ əbdʒɛktɪv wəd bi tə kæptʃɝ əz mɛni ʌv əm əz pɑsəbəl."

Our captured maps show large grasslands with very few inhabitants, which could be used as resting points along the way. We could strike across Murandy here," he pointed at a second map, which aides held up, "and come at Tar Valon from the south. If it pleases the Highest Daughter, we could raid at night, while the marath'damane are asleep. Our objective would be to capture as many of them as possible."

"ɪɾ ɪz wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðɪs ɹɪli kəd bi əkɑmplɪʃt," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst. tuɑn wɑz ɪntʃɹiɡd. "wʌt nʌmbɝz wəd wi bi eɪbəl tə juz fəɹ sətʃ ə ɹeɪd?"

"It is wondered if this really could be accomplished," Selucia Voiced. Tuon was intrigued. "What numbers would we be able to use for such a raid?"

"ɪf wi wɝ fʊli kəmɪɾəd?" julən æskt. "aɪ bɪliv aɪ kəd ɡæðɝ ʌp bɪtwin eɪɾi ən ə hʌnʒɹəd tɔɹeɪkən fəɹ ði əsɔlt."

"If we were fully committed?" Yulan asked. "I believe I could gather up between eighty and a hundred to'raken for the assault."

eɪɾi tə ə hʌnʒɹəd tɔɹeɪkən. soʊ, pɝhæps ɝaʊn θɹi hʌnʒɹəd soʊlʒɝz, wɪð ɪkwɪpmənt, livɪŋ ɹum tə bɹɪŋ bæk kæptʃɝd mɛɹəθdəmeɪn. θɹi hʌnʒɹəd wəd bi ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl fɔɹs fəɹ ə ɹeɪd laɪk ðɪs, bʌt ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə muv kwɪkli ən laɪtli, soʊ əz tə nɑt bi tʃɹæpt.

Eighty to a hundred to'raken. So, perhaps around three hundred soldiers, with equipment, leaving room to bring back captured marath'damane. Three hundred would be a considerable force for a raid like this, but they would have to move quickly and lightly, so as to not be trapped.

"ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ," dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən sɛd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ əɡɛn. "aɪ bɪliv dʒɛnɝəl julənz plæn əz mʌtʃ mɛɹət. ɪts nɑt wɪθaʊt pətɛnʃəl fəɹ ɡɹeɪt lɔs, bʌt wɪl nɛvɝ əv ənʌðɝ sətʃ ɑpɝtunəɾi. ɪf bɹɔt tə bɛɹ ɪn əɹ kənflɪkt, ðoʊz mɛɹəθdəmeɪn kəd dɪseɪbəl ʌs.

"If it pleases the Highest Daughter," General Galgan said, stepping forward again. "I believe General Yulan's plan has much merit. It is not without potential for great loss, but we will never have another such opportunity. If brought to bear in our conflict, those marath'damane could disable us.

ən ɪf wi kəd ɡeɪn æksɛs tə ðɪs wɛpən ə ðɛɹz, əɹ ivən ðɛɹ əbɪləɾi tə tʃɹævəl ɡɹeɪt dɪstənsəz. . . . wɛl, aɪ bɪliv ðət ðə ɹɪsk ʌv ɛvɹi tɔɹeɪkən ɪn əɹ ɑɹmi ɪz wɝθ ðə ɡeɪnz."

And if we could gain access to this weapon of theirs, or even their ability to travel great distances. . . . Well, I believe that the risk of every to'raken in our army is worth the gains."

"ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ," dʒɛnɝəl julən kəntɪnjud. "aʊɝ plæn kɔlz fəɹ ðə jus ə twɛnti skwɑdz ə ðə fɪsts ə hɛvən - tu hʌnʒɹəd tʃɹups toʊɾəl - ən fɪfti lɪŋk sʌldəm. wi θɪŋk ðæt, pɝhæps, ə smɔl ɡɹup ə blʌdnaɪvz wəd bi əpɹoʊpɹiəɾ əz wɛl."

"If it pleases the Highest Daughter," General Yulan continued. "Our plan calls for the use of twenty squads of the Fists of Heaven - two hundred troops total - and fifty linked sul'dam. We think that, perhaps, a small group of Bloodknives would be appropriate as well."

blʌdnaɪvz, ðə moʊst ɪlit mɛmbɝz ə ðə fɪst ə hɛvən, ɪtsɛlf ən ɪksklusɪv ɡɹup. julən ən ɡælɡən wɝ dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðɪs ækʃən! wʌn nɛvɝ kəmɪɾəd blʌdnaɪvz ənlɛs wʌn wɑz vɛɹi sɪɹiəs, fəɹ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðɛɹ mɪʃənz. ðɛɹ duɾi wɑz tə steɪ bɪhaɪn æftɝ ðə fɪsts wɪθdʒɹu ən kɑz dæmədʒ - əz mʌtʃ dæmədʒ əz pɑsəbəl - tə ði ɛnəmi. ɪf ðeɪ kəd pleɪs səm ə ðɛm ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɪð ɔɹɾɝz tə kɪl əz mɛni mɛɹəθdəmeɪn əz pɑsəbəl. . . .

Bloodknives, the most elite members of the Fist of Heaven, itself an exclusive group. Yulan and Galgan were dedicated to this action! One never committed Bloodknives unless one was very serious, for they did not return from their missions. Their duty was to stay behind after the Fists withdrew and cause damage - as much damage as possible - to the enemy. If they could place some of them in Tar Valon, with orders to kill as many marath'damane as possible. . . .

"ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl nɑt ɹiækt wɛl tə ðɪs ɹeɪd," tuɑn sɛd tə ɡælɡən. "ɪz i nɑt kənɛktəd tə ðiz mɛɹəθdəmeɪn?"

"The Dragon Reborn will not react well to this raid," Tuon said to Galgan. "Is he not connected to these marath'damane?"

"baɪ səm ɹɪpɔɹts," ɡælɡən sɛd. "ʌðɝz seɪ hiz əpoʊz tə ðɛm. stɪl ʌðɝz seɪ ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪz pɔnz. əɹ pʊɹ ɪntɛlədʒəns ɪn ðɪs ɛɹiə loʊɝz maɪ aɪz, haɪəs dɔɾɝ. aɪ hæv nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə sɔɹt ðə laɪz fɹəm ðə tʃɹuθs. əntɪl wɪv bɛɾɝ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, wi mʌst əsum ðə wɝst, ðət ðɪs ɹeɪd wɪl æŋɡɝ ɪm ɡɹeɪtli."

"By some reports," Galgan said. "Others say he is opposed to them. Still others say they are his pawns. Our poor intelligence in this area lowers my eyes, Highest Daughter. I have not been able to sort the lies from the truths. Until we have better information, we must assume the worst, that this raid will anger him greatly."

"æn jə stɪl θɪŋk ɪt wɝθwaɪl?"

"And you still think it worthwhile?"

"jɛs," ɡælɡən sɛd wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən. "ɪf ðiz mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɑɹ kənɛktəd tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðən wɪv ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɹizən tə stʃɹaɪk naʊ, bɪfɔɹ i kən juz əm əɡɛnst ʌs. pɝhæps ðə ɹeɪd wɪl ɛnɹeɪdʒ ɪm - bʌɾ ɪɾəl ɔlsoʊ wikən hɪm, wɪtʃ wɪl pleɪs jə ɪn ə bɛɾɝ pəzɪʃən fəɹ nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ wɪð hɪm."

"Yes," Galgan said without hesitation. "If these marath'damane are connected to the Dragon Reborn, then we have greater reason to strike now, before he can use them against us. Perhaps the raid will enrage him - but it will also weaken him, which will place you in a better position for negotiating with him."

tuɑn nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. əndaʊɾɪdli, ðɪs wɑz ðə dɪfəkəl dɪsɪʒən ə ði oʊmən. bʌɾ əɹ tʃɔɪs sim vɛɹi ɑbviəs. nɑɾ ə dɪfəkəl dɪsɪʒən əɾ ɔl. ɔl ə ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn mʌs bi kɑlɝd, ən ðɪs wɑz ən ɛksələnt weɪ tə wikən ɹɪzɪstəns tə ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl, paʊɝfəl bloʊ.

Tuon nodded thoughtfully. Undoubtedly, this was the difficult decision of the omen. But her choice seemed very obvious. Not a difficult decision at all. All of the marath'damane in Tar Valon must be collared, and this was an excellent way to weaken resistance to the Ever Victorious Army with a single, powerful blow.

bʌt ði oʊmən spoʊk ʌv ə dɪfəkəl dɪsɪʒən. ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd tə sɪlutʃə. "ɑɹ ðəɹ ɛni ɪn ðə ɹum u dɪsəpɹuv ə ðɪs plæn?" ðə vɔɪs æskt. "ɛni hu wəɾ ɔfɝ əbdʒɛkʃən tə wʌt dʒɛnɝəl julən ən ɪz mɛn əv ədvænst?"

But the omen spoke of a difficult decision. She gestured to Selucia. "Are there any in the room who disapprove of this plan?" the Voice asked. "Any who would offer objection to what General Yulan and his men have advanced?"

ðə blʌɾ ɪn ðə ɹum ɹəɡɑɹɾəd wʌn ənʌðɝ. bɛslən maɪɾ əv stɝd, bʌɾ i ɹɪmeɪn saɪlənt.

The Blood in the room regarded one another. Beslan might have stirred, but he remained silent.

ði ɔltɑɹənz hæd nɑt meɪɾ ɛni əbdʒɛkʃənz tə ðɛɹ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn biɪŋ kɑlɝd; ɪt sim ðeɪ hæd lɪɾəl tʃɹʌs fəɹ ðoʊz u kəd tʃænəl. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn əz pɹuɾənt əz ɑmɑdɪʃiə ɪn aʊtlɔɪŋ ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt niðɝ wɝ ðeɪ wɛlkəmɪŋ. bɛslən wəd nɑɾ əbdʒɛk tə ə stʃɹaɪk əɡɛns ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

The Altarans had not made any objections to their marath'damane being collared; it seemed they had little trust for those who could channel. They had not been as prudent as Amadicia in outlawing these Aes Sedai, but neither were they welcoming. Beslan would not object to a strike against the White Tower.

ʃi sæt bæk, weɪɾɪŋ . . . fəɹ wʌt? pɝhæps ðɪs wɑzn ðə dɪsɪʒən ði oʊmən hæd ɹəfɝd tə.

She sat back, waiting . . . For what? Perhaps this wasn't the decision the omen had referred to.

ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ tə ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd wɪð ðə ɹeɪd, bʌɾ ət ðət moʊmən ði oʊpənɪŋ ə ðə dɔɹz meɪɾ əɹ pɔz.

She opened her mouth to give the order to go forward with the raid, but at that moment the opening of the doors made her pause.

ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz u ɡɑɹɾəd ðə dɔɹ stɛpt əsaɪɾ ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, ædmɪɾɪŋ ə sɔɪhɪn u sɝvd ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. ðə stʃɹɔŋ-ɑɹmd mæn, məkoʊm, baʊd hɪmsɛlf loʊ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðə blæk bɹeɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ dʒɹɑpɪŋ tə ðə saɪɾ ən hɪɾɪŋ ðə taɪl flɔɹ. "meɪ ɪt pliz ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz, lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl taɪli kɪɝɡən wəd laɪk ən ɑɾiəns."

The Deathwatch Guards who guarded the door stepped aside a moment later, admitting a so'jhin who served in the hallway. The strong-armed man, Ma'combe, bowed himself low to the ground, the black braid over his right shoulder dropping to the side and hitting the tiled floor. "May it please the Daughter of the Nine Moons, Lieutenant-General Tylee Khirgan would like an audience."

ɡælɡən lʊkt ʃɑkt.

Galgan looked shocked.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" tuɑn æsk hɪm.

"What is it?" Tuon asked him.

"aɪ hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hæd ɹɪtɝnd, haɪəs dɔɾɝ," hi sɛd. "aɪ sədʒɛst ɪn hjumɪlɪɾi ðət ʃi bi ɡɪvən liv tə spik. ʃiz wʌn ə maɪ faɪnəst ɔfəsɝz."

"I had not realized that she had returned, Highest Daughter," he said. "I suggest in humility that she be given leave to speak. She is one of my finest officers."

"ʃi meɪ ɛntɝ," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst.

"She may enter," Selucia Voiced.

ə meɪl dækoʊvæl ɪn ə waɪt ɹoʊb ɛntɝd, pɹisiɾɪŋ ə wʊmən ɪn ɑɹmɝ, hɝ hɛlm ʌndɝ əɹ ɑɹm.

A male da'covale in a white robe entered, preceding a woman in armor, her helm under her arm.

dɑɹk ə skɪn, wɪð ʃɔɹt blæk hɛɹ wɔɹn ɪn taɪt kɝlz əɡɛnst əɹ skælp, ʃi wɑz tɔl ən lin. hɝ hɛɹ wɑz spɹɪŋkəld wɪð waɪɾ ət ðə tɛmpəlz. ði oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts ə hɝ ɑɹmɝ wɝ stʃɹaɪpt wɪð ɹɛd, jɛloʊ ən blu lækɝ, ən kɹikt əz ʃi wɔkt. ʃi wɑz oʊnli ʌv ðə loʊ blʌd - ɹisənli ɹeɪz baɪ dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡənz ɔɹɾɝ - bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn ɪnfɔɹmd ə ðɪs vaɪə ɹeɪkən. ʃi wɔɹ əɹ hɛɹ bɛɹli ʃeɪvd ə fɪŋɡɝz wɪdθ ʌp ðə saɪdz ə hɝ hɛd.

Dark of skin, with short black hair worn in tight curls against her scalp, she was tall and lean. Her hair was sprinkled with white at the temples. The overlapping plates of her armor were striped with red, yellow and blue lacquer, and creaked as she walked. She was only of the low Blood - recently raised by General Galgan's order - but she had been informed of this via raken. She wore her hair barely shaved a finger's width up the sides of her head.

taɪliz aɪz wɝ ɹɛd wɪð fətiɡ. dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ ðə sɛn ə swɛɾ ən ðə stɪŋk ə hɔɹs ʃi ɡeɪv ɔf, ʃi hæd kʌm stʃɹeɪt tə tuɑn əpɑn ɝaɪvɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ʃi wɑz fɑloʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum baɪ sɛvɹəl jʌŋɡɝ soʊlʒɝz, ɔlsoʊ ɪɡzɔstəd, wʌn bɛɹɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ bɹaʊn sæk. əpɑn ɹitʃɪŋ ðə sʌpləkeɪʃən speɪs - ə ɹɛd skwɛɹ ə klɔθ - ɔl wɛn daʊn ɑn ðɛɹ niz. ðə kɑmən soʊlʒɝz pɹəsiɾəd tə tʌtʃ fɔɹhɛdz tə ðə flɔɹ, ən taɪli dʒɝkt əz ɪf tə fɑloʊ, bʌt stɑp hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑz nɑt jɛɾ əkʌstəm tə biɪŋ wʌn ə ðə blʌd.

Tylee's eyes were red with fatigue. Judging by the scent of sweat and the stink of horse she gave off, she had come straight to Tuon upon arriving in the city. She was followed into the room by several younger soldiers, also exhausted, one bearing a large brown sack. Upon reaching the supplication space - a red square of cloth - all went down on their knees. The common soldiers proceeded to touch foreheads to the floor, and Tylee jerked as if to follow, but stopped herself. She was not yet accustomed to being one of the Blood.

"ɪɾ ɪz ɑbviəs ðət jə ɑɹ taɪɝd, wɔɹiɝ," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst. tuɑn lin fɔɹwɝd. "ɪɾ ɪz pɹəzum ðət juv nuz ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ ɪmpɔɹt?"

"It is obvious that you are tired, warrior," Selucia Voiced. Tuon leaned forward. "It is presumed that you have news of great import?"

taɪli ɹoʊz tə wʌn ni, ðən dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə saɪd. wʌn ə hɝ soʊlʒɝz ɹoʊz tə hɪz niz ən lɪftəɾ ʌp ɪz bɹaʊn sæk. ɪt wɑz steɪn ɑn ðə bɑɾəm wɪð ə dɑɹk, kɹʌstɪd lɪkwəd. blʌd.

Tylee rose to one knee, then gestured to the side. One of her soldiers rose to his knees and lifted up his brown sack. It was stained on the bottom with a dark, crusted liquid. Blood.

"ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ," taɪli sɛd, vɔɪs bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ ɪɡzɔstʃən. ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɝ mæn, ən i oʊpən ɪz sæk, dʌmpɪŋ θɪŋz ɑntu ðə flɔɹ. ðə hɛdz ə sɛvɹəl ænəməlz. ə bɔɹ, ə wʊlf, ən . . . ə hɔk? tuɑn fɛlt ə tʃɪl. ðət hɔks hɛd wɑz əz lɑɹdʒ əz ə pɝsənz. pɝhæps lɑɹdʒɝ.

"If it pleases the Highest Daughter," Tylee said, voice betraying exhaustion. She nodded to her man, and he opened his sack, dumping things onto the floor. The heads of several animals. A boar, a wolf, and . . . a hawk? Tuon felt a chill. That hawk's head was as large as a person's. Perhaps larger.

bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt . . . ɹaɪt. ðə hɛdz wɝ hɔɹəbli dɪfɔɹmd.

But they were not . . . right. The heads were horribly deformed.

ʃi kəd swɛɹ ðət ðə hɔks hɛd, wɪtʃ ɹoʊl soʊ ðət ʃi kəd si ðə feɪs klɪɹli, hæd hjumən aɪz. ən . . . ði ʌðɝ hɛdz hæd . . . hjumən fitʃɝz əz wɛl. tuɑn səpɹɛst ə ʃɪvɝ. wʌt faʊl oʊmən wɑz ðɪs?

She could swear that the hawk's head, which rolled so that she could see the face clearly, had human eyes. And . . . the other heads had . . . human features as well. Tuon suppressed a shiver. What foul omen was this?

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə minɪŋ ə ðɪs?" ɡælɡən dɪmændəd.

"What is the meaning of this?" Galgan demanded.

"aɪ pɹɪzum ðət ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ noʊz ə maɪ mɪlətɛɹi vɛntʃɝ əɡɛns ði il," taɪli sɛd, stɪl ɑn wʌn ni. taɪli hæd kæptʃɝd deɪmeɪn dʊɹɪŋ ðəɾ ɛnɡeɪdʒmənt, ðoʊ tuɑn dɪdnt noʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ðæt. dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən hæd bɪn əweɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɹɪtɝn wɪð səm kjʊɹiɑsəɾi tə ɹəsiv ðə fʊl stɔɹi.

"I presume that the Highest Daughter knows of my military venture against the Aiel," Tylee said, still on one knee. Tylee had captured damane during that engagement, though Tuon didn't know much more than that. General Galgan had been awaiting her return with some curiosity to receive the full story.

"ɪn maɪ vɛntʃɝ," taɪli kəntɪnjud, "aɪ wɑz dʒɔɪn baɪ mɛn ə vɛɹiəs næʃənælɪɾiz, nʌn ə hum hæd swɔɹn ði oʊðz. əl ɡɪv ə fʊl ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn əm wən ðəɹ ɪz taɪm." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ɡlænst ət ðə hɛdz. "ðiz . . . kɹitʃɝz . . . ətæk maɪ kʌmpəni dʊɹɪŋ əɹ ɹɪtɝn ɹaɪd, tɛn liɡz fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ. wi tʊk hɛvi kæʒəwəltiz. wi bɹɔt sɛvɹəl fʊl bɑɾiz əz wɛl əz ðiz hɛdz. ðeɪ wɔkt ɑn tu fit, laɪk mɛn, bʌt hæd mʌtʃ ði əpɪɹəns ʌv ænəməlz." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əɡɛn. "aɪ bɪliv əm tə bi wʌt səm ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən spik ʌv əz tʃɹɑləks. aɪ bɪliv əm tə bi kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ."

"In my venture," Tylee continued, "I was joined by men of various nationalities, none of whom had sworn the oaths. I will give a full report on them when there is time." She hesitated, then glanced at the heads. "These . . . creatures . . . attacked my company during our return ride, ten leagues from Ebou Dar. We took heavy casualties. We brought several full bodies as well as these heads. They walked on two feet, like men, but had much the appearance of animals." She hesitated again. "I believe them to be what some on this side of the ocean speak of as Trollocs. I believe them to be coming here."

keɪɑs. ðə blʌd bɪɡæn tə ɑɹɡju əbaʊt ði ɪmplɔzɪbɪlɪɾi ʌv ɪt. dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən ɪmiɾiətli ɔɹɾɝd ɪz ɔfəsɝz tə ɔɹɡənaɪz pətʃɹoʊlz ən sɛn ɹʌnɝz tə wɔɹn ʌv ə pətɛnʃəl ətæk ɑn ðə sɪɾi. ðə sʌldəm ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum hɝid fɔɹwɝd tə ɪnspɛk ðə hɛdz waɪl ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz kwaɪətli sɝaʊndəd tuɑn, tə ɡɪv ən ɛkstʃɹə leɪɝ ə dɪfɛns, wɑtʃɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn - blʌd, sɝvəns, ən soʊlʒɝz - wɪð ikwəl kɛɹ.

Chaos. The Blood began to argue about the implausibility of it. General Galgan immediately ordered his officers to organize patrols and send runners to warn of a potential attack on the city. The sul'dam at the side of the room hurried forward to inspect the heads while the Deathwatch Guards quietly surrounded Tuon, to give an extra layer of defense, watching everyone - Blood, servants, and soldiers - with equal care.

tuɑn fɛlt ʃi ʃəd bi ʃɑkt. bʌt, ɑdli, ʃi wɑznt. soʊ meɪtʃɹim wɑz nɑt mɪsteɪkən əbaʊt ðɪs, ʃi saɪn kʌvɝtli tə sɪlutʃə. ən ʃi hæɾ əsum tʃɹɑləks tə bi nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən supɝstɪʃən.

Tuon felt she should be shocked. But, oddly, she wasn't. So Matrim was not mistaken about this, she signed covertly to Selucia. And she had assumed Trollocs to be nothing more than superstition.

ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə hɛdz əɡɛn. ɹivoʊltɪŋ.

She glanced at the heads again. Revolting.

sɪlutʃə sim tʃɹʌbəld. ɑɹ ðəɹ ʌðɝ θɪŋz i sɛd ðət wi dɪskaʊntɪd, aɪ wʌndɝ?

Selucia seemed troubled. Are there other things he said that we discounted, I wonder?

tuɑn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. wi ʃæl əv tə æsk hɪm. aɪ ʃəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk tə hæv ɪm bæk. ʃi fɹoʊz;

Tuon hesitated. We shall have to ask him. I should very much like to have him back. She froze;

she hadn't meant to admit so much. She found her own emotions curious, however. She had felt safe with him, ridiculous though it seemed. And she wished he were with her now.

ðiz hɛdz wɝ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ pɹuf ðət ʃi nu vɛɹi lɪɾəl ə hɪm. ʃi ɹiəsɝɾəd kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə tʃæɾɝɪŋ kɹaʊd. sɪlutʃə vɔɪst, "ju wɪl saɪləns jʊɹsɛlvz."

These heads were yet another proof that she knew very little of him. She reasserted control of the chattering crowd. Selucia Voiced, "You will silence yourselves."

ðə ɹum fɛl stɪl, ðoʊ ðə blʌɾ ən ðə sʌldəm stɪl lʊk vɛɹi dɪstɝbd. taɪli stɪl nɛlt, hɛd baʊd, ðə soʊlʒɝ u hæd bɔɹn ðə hɛdz nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɝ. jɛs, ʃi wəɾ əv tə bi θɝoʊli kwɛstʃənd.

The room fell still, though the Blood and the sul'dam still looked very disturbed. Tylee still knelt, head bowed, the soldier who had borne the heads kneeling beside her. Yes, she would have to be thoroughly questioned.

"ðɪs nuz tʃeɪnʒəz lɪɾəl," sɪlutʃə vɔɪst. "wi wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi əwɛɹ ðət ðə læs bæɾəl əpɹoʊtʃɪz. wi əpɹiʃieɪt lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl taɪliz ɹɛvəleɪʃənz. ʃiz tə bi kəmɛndɪd. bʌt ðɪs oʊnli meɪks ɪt mɔɹ ɝdʒən ðət wi səbdu ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"This news changes little," Selucia Voiced. "We were already aware that the Last Battle approaches. We appreciate Lieutenant-General Tylee's revelations. She is to be commended. But this only makes it more urgent that we subdue the Dragon Reborn."

ðəɹ wɝ sɛvɹəl nɑdz fɹəm ðoʊz ɪn ðə ɹum, ɪnkluɾɪŋ dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən. bɛslən dɪd nɑt sim soʊ kwɪkli pɝsweɪɾəd. hi dʒʌs lʊk tʃɹʌbəld.

There were several nods from those in the room, including General Galgan. Beslan did not seem so quickly persuaded. He just looked troubled.

"ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ," taɪli sɛd, boʊɪŋ.

"If it pleases the Highest Daughter," Tylee said, bowing.

"ju ɑɹ əlaʊd tə spik."

"You are allowed to speak."

"ðiz læs fju wiks, aɪ hæv sin mɛni θɪŋz ðəɾ əv ɡɪvən mi θɔt," taɪli sɛd. "ivən bɪfɔɹ maɪ tʃɹups wɝ ətækt, aɪ wɑz wɝid. ðə wɪzdəm ən ɡɹeɪs ə ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ əndaʊɾɪdli lɛɾ əɹ si fɝðɝ ðən wʌn sətʃ əz aɪ, bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ əɹ kɑnkwɛsts soʊ fɑɹ ɪn ðɪs læn əv bɪn izi kəmpɛɹd tə wʌt maɪt kʌm. ɪf aɪ meɪ bi soʊ boʊld . . . aɪ bɪliv ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən ðoʊz əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð ɪm meɪ meɪk bɛɾɝ ælaɪz ðən ɛnəmiz."

"These last few weeks, I have seen many things that have given me thought," Tylee said. "Even before my troops were attacked, I was worried. The wisdom and grace of the Highest Daughter undoubtedly let her see further than one such as I, but I believe that our conquests so far in this land have been easy compared to what might come. If I may be so bold . . . I believe that the Dragon Reborn and those associated with him may make better allies than enemies."

aɪ ti wɑz ə boʊl steɪtmənt. tuɑn lin fɔɹwɝd, lækɝd neɪlz klɪkɪŋ ɑn ði ɑɹmɹɛsts ə hɝ tʃɛɹ. mɛni ʌv ðə loʊ blʌd wəd bi soʊ ɪn ɑ ət miɾɪŋ wʌn ə ði ɛmpɹɛsəz haʊshoʊld, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə haɪəs dɔɾɝ, ðət ðeɪ wəd nɑt dɛɹ spik. jɛt ðɪs wʊmən ɔfɝd sədʒɛstʃənz? ɪn dɝɛkt ɑpəzɪʃən tə tuɑnz pʌblɪʃt wɪl?

I t was a bold statement. Tuon leaned forward, lacquered nails clicking on the armrests of her chair. Many of the low Blood would be so in awe at meeting one of the Empress's household, much less the Highest Daughter, that they would not dare speak. Yet this woman offered suggestions? In direct opposition to Tuon's published will?

"ə dɪfəkəl dɪsɪʒən ɪz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ə dɪsɪʒən wɛɹ boʊθ saɪdz ɑɹ ikwəli mætʃt, tuɑn,"

"A difficult decision is not always a decision where both sides are equally matched, Tuon,"

sɪlutʃə sɛd sʌɾənli. "pɝhæps, ɪn ðɪs keɪs, ə dɪfəkəl dɪsɪʒən ɪz wʌn ðəɾ ɪz ɹaɪt, bʌt ɹikwaɪɝz ən ɪmpləkeɪʃən ə fɔlt əz wɛl."

Selucia said suddenly. "Perhaps, in this case, a difficult decision is one that is right, but requires an implication of fault as well."

tuɑn blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. jɛs, ʃi ɹilaɪzd. sɪlutʃə ɪz maɪ tʃɹuθspikɝ naʊ. ɪt wəd teɪk taɪm tə əkʌstəm hɝsɛlf tə ðə wʊmən ɪn ðət ɹoʊl. ɪt hæd bɪn jɪɹz sɪns sɪlutʃə hæd kɝɛktəɾ əɹ ɹipɹuvd əɹ ɪn pʌblɪk.

Tuon blinked in surprise. Yes, she realized. Selucia is my Truthspeaker now. It would take time to accustom herself to the woman in that role. It had been years since Selucia had corrected or reproved her in public.

ən jɛt, miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ɪn pɝsən? ʃi dɪd nid tə kɑntæk hɪm, ən hæd plæn tə. bʌt wəɾ ɪt nɑt bi bɛɾɝ tə ɡoʊ tə hɪm ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ, hɪz ɑɹmiz dɪfiɾəd, ðə waɪt taʊɝ tɔɹn daʊn? ʃi niɾəd ɪm bɹɔt tə ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn ʌndɝ vɛɹi kəntʃɹoʊl sɝkəmstænsəz, wɪð ði ʌndɝstændɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz tə səbmɪt tə hɝ əθɔɹəɾi.

And yet, meeting with the Dragon Reborn, in person? She did need to contact him, and had planned to. But would it not be better to go to him in strength, his armies defeated, the White Tower torn down? She needed him brought to the Crystal Throne under very controlled circumstances, with the understanding that he was to submit to her authority.

ən jɛt . . . wɪð sintʃæn ɪn ɹɪbɛljən . . . wɪð əɹ pəzɪʃən hɪɹ ɪn ɔltɑɹə bɛɹli steɪbəlaɪzd . . .

And yet . . . with Seanchan in rebellion . . . with her position here in Altara barely stabilized . . .

wɛl, pɝhæps səm taɪm tə θɪŋk - səm taɪm tə teɪk ə fju dip bɹɛθs ən sɪkjʊɹ wʌt ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi hæd - wəd bi wɝθ dɪleɪɪŋ əɹ stʃɹaɪk ɑn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Well, perhaps some time to think - some time to take a few deep breaths and secure what she already had - would be worth delaying her strike on the White Tower.

"dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən, sɛn ɹeɪkən tə əɹ fɔɹsɪz ɪn ɑlməθ pleɪn ən istɝn ɔltɑɹə," ʃi sɛd fɝmli.

"General Galgan, send raken to our forces in Almoth Plain and eastern Altara," she said firmly.

"tɛl əm tə hoʊld əɹ ɪntʃɹəsts, bʌɾ əvɔɪd kɑnfɹənteɪʃən wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ən ɹɪplaɪ tə hɪz ɹɪkwɛs fəɹ ə miɾɪŋ. ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz wɪl mit wɪð hɪm."

"Tell them to hold our interests, but avoid confrontation with the Dragon Reborn. And reply to his request for a meeting. The Daughter of the Nine Moons will meet with him."

dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən nɑɾəd, boʊɪŋ.

General Galgan nodded, bowing.

ɔɹɾɝ mʌs bi bɹɔt tə ðə wɝld. ɪf ʃi hæd tə də ðət baɪ loʊɝɪŋ əɹ aɪz slaɪtli ən miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðən soʊ bi ɪt.

Order must be brought to the world. If she had to do that by lowering her eyes slightly and meeting with the Dragon Reborn, then so be it.

ɑdli, ʃi fɛl hɝsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ - wʌns əɡɛn - ðət meɪtʃɹim wɝ stɪl wɪð hɝ. ʃi cʊɾə pʊɾ ɪz nɑlədʒ ə ðɪs ɹænd ælθɹ tə ɡʊd jus ɪn pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə miɾɪŋ. steɪ wɛl, jə kjʊɹiəs mæn, ʃi θɔt, ɡlænsɪŋ bæk ət ðə bælkəni, nɔɹθwɝd. də nɑt dɪɡ jɝsɛlf ɪndə tʃɹʌbəl dipɝ ðən jə kən klaɪm tə fɹiɾəm. jə ɑɹ pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz naʊ. ɹɪmɛmbɝ tə ækt əpɹoʊpɹiɪtli.

Oddly, she felt herself wishing - once again - that Matrim were still with her. She could have put his knowledge of this Rand al'Thor to good use in preparing for the meeting. Stay well, you curious man, she thought, glancing back at the balcony, northward. Do not dig yourself into trouble deeper than you can climb to freedom. You are Prince of the Ravens now. Remember to act appropriately.

wɛɹɛvɝ ɪts jə ɑɹ.

Wherever it is you are.

tʃæptɝ twɛnti

CHAPTER 20

ɑn ə bɹoʊkən ɹoʊd "wɪmən," mæt dɪklɛɹɾ əz i ɹoʊd pɪps daʊn ðə dʌsti, lɪɾəl-juzd ɹoʊd, "ɑɹ laɪk mjulz." hi fɹaʊnd. "weɪt. noʊ. ɡoʊts. wɪmən ɑɹ laɪk ɡoʊts. ɪksɛpt ɛvɹi fleɪmɪŋ wʌn θɪŋks ʃiz ə hɔɹs ɪnstɛd, ən ə pɹaɪz ɹeɪsɪŋ mɛɹ tə but. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi, tælmɑnz?"

On a Broken Road "Women," Mat declared as he rode Pips down the dusty, little-used road, "are like mules." He frowned. "Wait. No. Goats. Women are like goats. Except every flaming one thinks she's a horse instead, and a prize racing mare to boot. Do you understand me, Talmanes?"

"pjʊɹ poʊətʃɹi, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, tæmpɪŋ ðə təbæk daʊn ɪndə hɪz paɪp.

"Pure poetry, Mat," Talmanes said, tamping the tabac down into his pipe.

mæt flɪkt ɪz ɹeɪnz, pɪps kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə plɑɾ əlɔŋ. tɔl θɹi-niɾəl paɪnz laɪn ðə saɪdz ə ðə stoʊn ɹoʊdweɪ. ðeɪd bɪn lʌki tə faɪn ðɪs eɪntʃən ɹoʊd, wɪtʃ mʌst əv bɪn meɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ. ɪt wɑz moʊsli oʊvɝɡɹoʊn, ðə stoʊnz ʃæɾɝd ɪn mɛni pleɪsəz, lɑɹdʒ sɛkʃənz ə ðə ɹoʊdweɪ dʒʌst . . . wɛl, dʒʌst ɡɔn.

Mat flicked his reins, Pips continuing to plod along. Tall three-needle pines lined the sides of the stone roadway. They'd been lucky to find this ancient road, which must have been made before the Breaking. It was mostly overgrown, the stones shattered in many places, large sections of the roadway just . . . well, just gone.

sæpəlɪŋ paɪnz hæd bɪɡʌn tə spɹaʊɾ ət ðə saɪdz ə ðə ɹoʊdweɪ ən bɪtwin ɹɑks, mɪniətʃʊɹ vɝʒənz ə ðɛɹ taʊɝɪŋ fɑðɝz əbʌv. ðə pæθ wɑz waɪd, ɪf vɛɹi ɹʌf, wɪtʃ wɑz ɡʊd. mæt hæd sɛvən θaʊzən mɛn wɪð hɪm, ɔl maʊntəd, ən ðeɪd bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ hɑɹɾ ɪn ðə lɪɾəl ʌndɝ ə wik ðeɪd spɛn tʃɹævlɪŋ sɪns sɛndɪŋ tuɑn bæk tə ɛbu dɑɹ.

Sapling pines had begun to sprout at the sides of the roadway and between rocks, miniature versions of their towering fathers above. The path was wide, if very rough, which was good. Mat had seven thousand men with him, all mounted, and they'd been riding hard in the little under a week they'd spent traveling since sending Tuon back to Ebou Dar.

"ɹizənɪŋ wɪð ə wʊmən ɪz ɪmpɑsəbəl," mæt kəntɪnjud, aɪz fɔɹwɝd. "ɪts laɪk . . . wɛl, ɹizənɪŋ wɪð ə wʊmən ɪz laɪk sɪɾɪŋ daʊn tə ə fɹɛnli ɡeɪm ə daɪs. oʊnli ðə wʊmən ɹəfjuzəz tə æknɑlɪdʒ ðə beɪsɪk blʌɾi ɹulz ə ðə ɡeɪm. ə mæn, hɪl tʃit jə - bʌt hɪl də ɪɾ ɑnəsli.

"Reasoning with a woman is impossible," Mat continued, eyes forward. "It's like . . . Well, reasoning with a woman is like sitting down to a friendly game of dice. Only the woman refuses to acknowledge the basic bloody rules of the game. A man, he'll cheat you - but he'll do it honestly.

hɪl juz loʊɾəd daɪs, soʊ ðət jə θɪŋk jəɹ luzɪŋ baɪ tʃæns. ən ɪf jə ɑɹən klɛvɝ ɪnʌf tə spɑt wʌt hiz duɪŋ, ðən meɪbi hi dɪzɝvz tə teɪk jəɹ kɔɪn. ən ðæts ðæt.

He'll use loaded dice, so that you think you're losing by chance. And if you aren't clever enough to spot what he's doing, then maybe he deserves to take your coin. And that's that.

"ə wʊmən, ðoʊ, ʃɪl sɪt daʊn tə ðət seɪm ɡeɪm ən ʃɪl smaɪl, ən æk laɪk ʃiz ɡoʊɪŋ tə pleɪ. oʊnli wən ɪts əɹ tɝn tə θɹoʊ, ʃɪl tɔs ə pɛɹ ə hɝ oʊn daɪs ðəɾ ɑɹ blæŋk ɑn ɔl sɪks saɪdz. nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl pɪp ʃoʊɪŋ. ʃɪl ɪnspɛkt əɹ θɹoʊ, ðən ʃɪl lʊk ʌp ət jə ən seɪ, 'klɪɹli aɪ dʒʌst wʌn.'

"A woman, though, she'll sit down to that same game and she'll smile, and act like she's going to play. Only when it's her turn to throw, she'll toss a pair of her own dice that are blank on all six sides. Not a single pip showing. She'll inspect her throw, then she'll look up at you and say, 'Clearly I just won.'

"naʊ, jəl skɹætʃ jəɹ hɛɾ ən lʊk ət ðə daɪs. ðən jəl lʊk ʌp ət hɝ, ðən daʊn ət ðə daɪs əɡɛn. 'bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹən ɛni pɪps ɑn ðiz daɪs,' jəl seɪ.

"Now, you'll scratch your head and look at the dice. Then you'll look up at her, then down at the dice again. 'But there aren't any pips on these dice,' you'll say.

" 'jɛs ðəɹ ɑɹ,' ʃɪl seɪ. 'æn boʊθ daɪs ɹoʊld ə wʌn.'

" 'Yes there are,' she'll say. 'And both dice rolled a one.'

" 'ðæts ɪɡzækli ðə nʌmbɝ jə nid tə wɪn,' jəl seɪ.

" 'That's exactly the number you need to win,' you'll say.

" 'wʌɾ ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns,' ʃɪl ɹɪplaɪ, ðən bɪɡɪn tə skup ʌp jəɹ kɔɪnz. ən jəl sɪt ðɛɹ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹæp jəɹ hɛd 'baʊt wʌt dʒʌs hæpənd. ən jəl ɹilaɪz sʌmθɪŋ. ə pɛɹ ʌv wʌnz ɪzən ðə wɪnɪŋ θɹoʊ! nɑt wən jə θɹu ə sɪks ɑn jəɹ tɝn. ðət minz ʃi niɾəd ə pɛɹ ə tuz ɪnstɛd! ɪksaɪɾədli, jəl ɪkspleɪn wʌt juv dɪskʌvɝd. oʊnli ðɛn, dʒju noʊ wʌt ʃɪl du?"

" 'What a coincidence,' she'll reply, then begin to scoop up your coins. And you'll sit there, trying to wrap your head 'bout what just happened. And you'll realize something. A pair of ones isn't the winning throw! Not when you threw a six on your turn. That means she needed a pair of twos instead! Excitedly, you'll explain what you've discovered. Only then, do you know what she'll do?"

"noʊ aɪdiə, mæt," tælmɑnz ɹɪplaɪd, tʃuɪŋ ɑn ɪz paɪp, ə θɪn wɪsp ə smoʊk kɝlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə boʊl.

"No idea, Mat," Talmanes replied, chewing on his pipe, a thin wisp of smoke curling out of the bowl.

"ðɛn ʃɪl ɹitʃ oʊvɝ," mæt sɛd, "æn ɹʌb ðə blæŋk feɪsəz ə hɝ daɪs. ən ðɛn, wɪð ə pɝfəkli stʃɹeɪt feɪs, ʃɪl seɪ, 'aɪm sɑɹi. ðəɹ wɑz ə spɑɾ ə dɝɾ ɑn ðə daɪs. klɪɹli jə kən si ðət ðeɪ æktʃəli  keɪm ʌp əz tuz!' ən ʃɪl bɪliv ɪt. ʃɪl blʌɾi bɪliv ɪt!"

"Then she'll reach over," Mat said, "and rub the blank faces of her dice. And then, with a perfectly straight face, she'll say, 'I'm sorry. There was a spot of dirt on the dice. Clearly you can see that they actually came up as twos!' And she'll believe it. She'll bloody believe it!"

"ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl," tælmɑnz sɛd.

"Incredible," Talmanes said.

"oʊnli ðæts nɑt ði ɛn ʌv ɪt!"

"Only that's not the end of it!"

"aɪ hæd pɹəzum ðəɾ ɪt wʊdn bi, mæt."

"I had presumed that it wouldn't be, Mat."

"ʃi skups ʌp ɔl ə jəɹ kɔɪnz," mæt sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð wʌn hænd, ði ʌðɝ stɛɾiɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ əkɹɔs ɪz sæɾəl. "æn ðən ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wʊmən ɪn ðə ɹum wɪl kʌm oʊvɝ ən kənɡɹætʃəleɪɾ əɹ ɑn θɹoʊɪŋ ðət pɛɹ ə tuz! ðə mɔɹ jə kəmpleɪn, ðə mɔɹ ə ðoʊz blʌɾi wɪmən wɪl dʒɔɪn ði ɑɹɡjəmənt. jəl bi aʊtnʌmbɝɾ ɪn ə moʊmənt, ən itʃ ə ðoʊz wɪmən wɪl ɪkspleɪn tə jə haʊ ðoʊz daɪs klɪɹli ɹɛd tuz, ən haʊ jə ɹɪli nid tə stɑp bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk ə tʃaɪld. ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl fleɪmɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛm wɪl si ðə tuz! ivən ðə pɹuɾɪʃ wʊmən u hæz heɪɾəd jəɹ wʊmən fɹəm bɝθ - sɪns jəɹ wʊmənz ɡɹæni stoʊl ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ɡɹæniz hʌnikeɪk ɹɛsəpi wən ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ meɪdz -  ðət wʊmən wɪl saɪɾ əɡɛns ju."
