"She scoops up all of your coins," Mat said, gesturing with one hand, the other steadying his ashandarei across his saddle. "And then every other woman in the room will come over and congratulate her on throwing that pair of twos! The more you complain, the more of those bloody women will join the argument. You'll be outnumbered in a moment, and each of those women will explain to you how those dice clearly read twos, and how you really need to stop behaving like a child. Every single flaming one of them will see the twos! Even the prudish woman who has hated your woman from birth - since your woman's granny stole the other woman's granny's honeycake recipe when they were both maids -  that woman will side against you."

"ðeɪ ɑɹ nəfɛɹiəs kɹitʃɝz ɪndid," tælmɑnz sɛd, vɔɪs flæɾ ən ivən. tælmɑnz ɹɛɹli smaɪld.

"They are nefarious creatures indeed," Talmanes said, voice flat and even. Talmanes rarely smiled.

"baɪ ðə taɪm ðəɹ dʌn," mæt kəntɪnjud, ɔlmoʊs mɔɹ tə hɪmsɛlf, "jul bi lɛft wɪð noʊ kɔɪn, sɛvɹəl lɪsts' wɝθ ʌv ɛɹənz tə ɹʌn ən wʌt kloʊðɪŋ tə wɛɹ ən ə splɪɾɪŋ hɛdeɪk. jəl sɪt ðəɹ ən stɛɹ ət ðə teɪbəl ən bɪɡɪn tə wʌndɝ, dʒʌs meɪbi, ɪf ðoʊz daɪs dɪdn ɹɛd tuz æftɝ ɔl. ɪf oʊnli tə pɹəzɝv wʌts lɛft ə jəɹ sænəɾi. ðæts wʌɾ ɪts laɪk tə ɹizən wɪð ə wʊmən, aɪ tɛl ju."

"By the time they're done," Mat continued, almost more to himself, "you'll be left with no coin, several lists' worth of errands to run and what clothing to wear and a splitting headache. You'll sit there and stare at the table and begin to wonder, just maybe, if those dice didn't read twos after all. If only to preserve what's left of your sanity. That's what it's like to reason with a woman, I tell you."

"æn jə dɪd soʊ. ət lɛŋθ."

"And you did so. At length."

"ju ɑɹən meɪkɪŋ spɔɹɾ ə mi, ɑɹ ju?"

"You aren't making sport of me, are you?"

"waɪ, mæt!" ðə kɛɹhinɪn sɛd. "ju noʊ aɪd nɛvɝ də sətʃ ə θɪŋ."

"Why, Mat!" the Cairhienin said. "You know I'd never do such a thing."

"tu bæd," mæt mʌɾɝd, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɪm səspɪʃəsli. "aɪ kəd juz ə læf." hi lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "veɪnɪn! wɛɹ ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz blɪstɝd bæksaɪɾ ɑɹ wi?"

"Too bad," Mat muttered, glancing at him suspiciously. "I could use a laugh." He looked over his shoulder. "Vanin! Where on the Dark One's blistered backside are we?"

ðə fæt fɔɹmɝ hɔɹsɛθif lʊkt ʌp. hi ɹoʊɾ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns bɪhaɪn mæt, ən i kæɹiɾ ə mæp ə ði ɛɹiə ənɹoʊld ən foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ə bɔɹd soʊ hi kəd ɹiɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl. hid bɪn pɔɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ ðə bɛɾɝ hæf ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. mæt hæɾ æskt ɪm tə ɡɛɾ əm θɹu mʊɹændi kwaɪətli, nɑt ɡɛɾ əm lɔst ɪn ðə maʊntənz fəɹ mʌnθs!

The fat former horsethief looked up. He rode a short distance behind Mat, and he carried a map of the area unrolled and folded across a board so he could read it in the saddle. He'd been poring over the bloody thing the better half of the morning. Mat had asked him to get them through Murandy quietly, not get them lost in the mountains for months!

"ðæts blaɪndɝz pik," veɪnɪn sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð ə pʌdʒi fɪŋɡɝ təwɔɹɾ ə flæt-tɑp maʊntən dʒʌs bɛɹli vɪzəbəl oʊvɝ ðə tɪps ə ðə paɪnz. "æt list, aɪ θɪŋk ɪɾ ɪz. ɪt maɪt bi maʊn sɑɹɾələn."

"That's Blinder's Peak," Vanin said, gesturing with a pudgy finger toward a flat-topped mountain just barely visible over the tips of the pines. "At least, I think it is. It might be Mount Sardlen."

ðə skwɑt hɪl dɪdn lʊk laɪk mʌtʃ ʌv ə maʊntən; ɪt bɛɹli hæɾ ɛni snoʊ ətɑp ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, fju "maʊntənz" ɪn ðɪs ɛɹiə wɝ ɪmpɹɛsɪv, nɑt kəmpɛɹd tə ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, bæk nɪɹ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. hɪɹ, nɔɹθist ə ðə deɪmoʊnə ɹeɪnʒ, ðə lændskeɪp fɛl ɪndə ə ɡɹupɪŋ ə loʊ fʊthɪlz. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tɝeɪn, bʌt nævəɡəbəl, ɪf wʌn wɝ dɪtɝmənd. ən mæt wɑz dɪtɝmənd. dɪtɝmənd nɑt tə bi pɪn ɪn baɪ ðə sintʃæn əɡɛn, dɪtɝmənd nɑt tə bi sin baɪ ɛni hu dɪdn əv tə noʊ hi wɑz ðɛɹ. hid peɪd ðə bʊtʃɝ tu mʌtʃ soʊ fɑɹ. hi wɑntəɾ aʊɾ ə ðɪs hæŋmənz nus ʌv ə kʌntʃɹi.

The squat hill didn't look like much of a mountain; it barely had any snow atop it. Of course, few "mountains" in this area were impressive, not compared to the Mountains of Mist, back near the Two Rivers. Here, northeast of the Damona range, the landscape fell into a grouping of low foothills. It was difficult terrain, but navigable, if one were determined. And Mat was determined. Determined not to be pinned in by the Seanchan again, determined not to be seen by any who didn't have to know he was there. He'd paid the butcher too much so far. He wanted out of this hangman's noose of a country.

"wɛl," mæt sɛd, ɹeɪnɪŋ pɪps bæk tə ɹaɪd bɪsaɪd veɪnɪn, "wɪtʃ ə ðoʊz maʊntənz ɪz ɪt? meɪbi wi ʃəd ɡoʊ æsk mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl əɡɛn."

"Well," Mat said, reining Pips back to ride beside Vanin, "which of those mountains is it? Maybe we should go ask Master Roidelle again."

ðə mæp bɪlɔŋ tə ðə mæstɝ mæpmeɪkɝ; ɪt wɑz oʊnli kəz ə hɪz pɹɛzəns ðət ðeɪd bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪn ðɪs ɹoʊdweɪ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. bʌt veɪnɪn ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn biɪŋ ðə wʌn tə ɡaɪd ðə tʃɹup - ə mæpmeɪkɝ wɑzn ðə seɪm θɪŋ əz ə skaʊt. jə dɪdn əv ə dʌsti kɑɹtɑɡɹəfɝ ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ən lɛd ðə weɪ fəɹ ju, veɪnɪn ɪnsɪstəd.

The map belonged to the master mapmaker; it was only because of his presence that they'd been able to find this roadway in the first place. But Vanin insisted on being the one to guide the troop - a mapmaker wasn't the same thing as a scout. You didn't have a dusty cartographer ride out and lead the way for you, Vanin insisted.

ɪn tʃɹuθ, mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl dɪdn əv ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪkspɪɹiəns biɪŋ ə ɡaɪd. hi wɑz ə skɑlɝ, ən ækədɛmɪk. hi kəɾ ɪkspleɪn ə mæp fəɹ jə pɝfəkli, bʌɾ i hæɾ əz mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl əz veɪnɪn meɪkɪŋ sɛns ʌv wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ, sɪns ðɪs ɹoʊdweɪ wɑz soʊ dɪsdʒɔɪntɪɾ ən bɹoʊkən, ðə paɪnz haɪ ɪnʌf tə əbskjʊɹ lændmɑɹks, ðə hɪltɑps ɔl nɪɹli aɪdɛntɪkəl.

In truth, Master Roidelle didn't have a lot of experience being a guide. He was a scholar, an academic. He could explain a map for you perfectly, but he had as much trouble as Vanin making sense of where they were, since this roadway was so disjointed and broken, the pines high enough to obscure landmarks, the hilltops all nearly identical.

ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz ɔlsoʊ ðə fæk ðət veɪnɪn sim θɹɛɾənd baɪ ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə mæpmeɪkɝ, əz ɪf i wɝ wɝiɾ əbaʊt biɪŋ ənsiɾɪd fɹəm ɪz pəzɪʃən ɡaɪɾɪŋ mæt ən ðə bænd. mæt hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd sətʃ ən ɪmoʊʃən fɹəm ði oʊvɝweɪt hɔɹsɛθif. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm əmjuzd ɪf ðeɪ wɝn lɔst soʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə fleɪmɪŋ taɪm.

Of course, there was also the fact that Vanin seemed threatened by the presence of the mapmaker, as if he were worried about being unseated from his position guiding Mat and the Band. Mat had never expected such an emotion from the overweight horsethief. It might have been enough to make him amused if they weren't lost so much of the flaming time.

veɪnɪn skaʊld. "aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ əz tə bi maʊn sɑɹɾələn. jɛs. ɪts ɡɑt tə bi."

Vanin scowled. "I think that has to be Mount Sardlen. Yes. It's got to be."

"wɪtʃ minz . . . ?"

"Which means . . . ?"

"wɪtʃ minz wi kip hɛɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊdweɪ," veɪnɪn sɛd. "ðə seɪm θɪŋ aɪ toʊl jə ən aʊɝ əɡoʊ. wi kæn blʌɾi mɑɹtʃ ən ɑɹmi θɹu ə fɔɹəs ðɪs θɪk, naʊ kən wi? ðət minz steɪɪŋ ɑn ðə stoʊnz."

"Which means we keep heading along the roadway," Vanin said. "The same thing I told you an hour ago. We can't bloody march an army through a forest this thick, now can we? That means staying on the stones."

"aɪm dʒʌst æskɪŋ," mæt sɛd, pʊlɪŋ daʊn ðə bɹɪm ə hɪz hæɾ əɡɛns ðə sʌn. "ə kəmændɝz ɡɑt tə æsk θɪŋz laɪk ðɪs."

"I'm just asking," Mat said, pulling down the brim of his hat against the sun. "A commander's got to ask things like this."

"aɪ ʃəd ɹaɪɾ əhɛd," veɪnɪn sɛd, skaʊlɪŋ əɡɛn. hi wɑz fɑn ə skaʊlz. "ɪf ðəɾ ɪz maʊn sɑɹɾələn, ðəɹ ʃəd bi ə vɪlədʒ ə fɛɹ saɪz ən aʊɝ əɹ tu fɝðɝ əlɔŋ. aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə spɑɾ ɪt fɹəm ðə nɛkst ɹaɪz."

"I should ride ahead," Vanin said, scowling again. He was fond of scowls. "If that is Mount Sardlen, there should be a village of fair size an hour or two further along. I might be able to spot it from the next rise."

"ɡoʊ, ðɛn," mæt sɛd. ðeɪ hæɾ ədvæns skaʊts aʊt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt nʌn ə ðɛm wɝ əz ɡʊɾ əz veɪnɪn. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz saɪz, ðə mæn kəd snik kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ən ɛnəmi fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən tə kaʊn ðə wɪskɝz ɪn ðə kæmp ɡɑɹdz' bɪɹdz ən nɛvɝ bi sin. hid pɹɑbli meɪk ɔf wɪð ðɛɹ stu, tu.

"Go, then," Mat said. They had advance scouts out, of course, but none of them were as good as Vanin. Despite his size, the man could sneak close enough to an enemy fortification to count the whiskers in the camp guards' beards and never be seen. He'd probably make off with their stew, too.

veɪnɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz i ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə mæp əɡɛn. "æktʃəli ," hi mʌɾɝd, "naʊ ðəɾ aɪ θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt, meɪbi ðæts fævlɛn maʊntən. . . ." hi sɛɾ ɔf əɾ ə tʃɹɑt bɪfɔɹ mæt kəɾ əbdʒɛkt.

Vanin shook his head as he regarded the map again. "Actually," he muttered, "now that I think about it, maybe that's Favlend Mountain. . . ." He set off at a trot before Mat could object.

mæt saɪd, hilɪŋ pɪps tə kætʃ ʌp tə tælmɑnz. ðə kɛɹhinɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi kəd bi ən ɪntɛns wʌn, tælmɑnz. ɝli ɪn ðɛɹ əsoʊsieɪʃən, mæt hæɾ əsumd ɪm tə bi stɝn, əneɪbəl tə hæv fʌn. hi wɑz lɝnɪŋ bɛɾɝ. tælmɑnz wɑzn stɝn, hi wɑz dʒʌst ɹɪzɝvd. bʌɾ ət taɪmz, ðəɹ sim tə bi ə twɪŋkəl tə ðə noʊbəlmənz aɪz, əz ɪf i wɝ læfɪŋ ət ðə wɝld, dɪspaɪt ðət sɛt dʒɔ ən ɪz ənsmaɪlɪŋ lɪps.

Mat sighed, heeling Pips to catch up to Talmanes. The Cairhienin shook his head. He could be an intense one, Talmanes. Early in their association, Mat had assumed him to be stern, unable to have fun. He was learning better. Talmanes wasn't stern, he was just reserved. But at times, there seemed to be a twinkle to the nobleman's eyes, as if he were laughing at the world, despite that set jaw and his unsmiling lips.

tədeɪ, hi wɔɹ ə ɹɛd koʊt, tʃɹɪmd wɪð ɡoʊld, ən ɪz fɔɹhɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd ən paʊɾɝd æftɝ kɛɹhinɪn fæʃən. ɪt lʊk blʌɾi ɹɪdɪkjələs, bʌɾ u wɑz mæt tə dʒʌdʒ? tælmɑnz maɪɾ əv tɛɹəbəl fæʃən sɛns, bʌɾ i wɑz ə lɔɪəl ɔfəsɝ ən ə ɡʊd mæn. bɪsaɪdz, hi hæɾ ɛksələn teɪst ɪn waɪn.

Today, he wore a red coat, trimmed with gold, and his forehead was shaved and powdered after Cairhienin fashion. It looked bloody ridiculous, but who was Mat to judge? Talmanes might have terrible fashion sense, but he was a loyal officer and a good man. Besides, he had excellent taste in wine.

"doʊn lʊk soʊ ɡlʌm, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, pʌfɪŋ ɑn ɪz ɡoʊld-ɹɪm paɪp. wɛɹəɾ i ɡɑɾən ðæt, ɛniweɪ? mæt dɪdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪm hævɪŋ ɪt bɪfɔɹ. "jɔɹ mɛn əv fʊl bɛliz, fʊl pɑkəts, ən ðeɪ dʒʌst wʌn ə ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝi. nɑt mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ðəɾ ə soʊlʒɝ kən æsk fɔɹ."

"Don't look so glum, Mat," Talmanes said, puffing on his gold-rimmed pipe. Where'd he gotten that, anyway? Mat didn't remember him having it before. "Your men have full bellies, full pockets, and they just won a great victory. Not much more than that a soldier can ask for."

"wi bɛɹiɾ ə θaʊzən mɛn," mæt sɛd. "ðæts noʊ vɪktɝi." ðə mɛmɹiz ɪn ɪz hɛd - ðə wʌnz ðət wɝn ɪz - sɛɾ i ʃəd bi pɹaʊd. ðə bæɾəl hæd ɡɔn wɛl. bʌt ðəɹ wɝ stɪl ðoʊz dɛɾ u hæd dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn hɪm.

"We buried a thousand men," Mat said. "That's no victory." The memories in his head - the ones that weren't his - said he should be proud. The battle had gone well. But there were still those dead who had depended on him.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz lɔsəz," tælmɑnz sɛd. "ju kæn lɛɾ əm it jə ʌp, mæt. ɪt hæpənz."

"There are always losses," Talmanes said. "You can't let them eat you up, Mat. It happens."

"ðɛɹ ɑɹən lɔsəz wən jə doʊn faɪɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs."

"There aren't losses when you don't fight in the first place."

"ðɛn waɪ ɹaɪd tə bæɾəl soʊ ɔfən?"

"Then why ride to battle so often?"

"aɪ oʊnli faɪt wən aɪ kæn əvɔɪɾ ɪt!" mæt snæpt. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz, hi oʊnli fɔt wən i hæd tə. wən ðeɪ tʃɹæp hɪm! waɪ dɪd ðət sim tə hæpən ɛvɹi taɪm i tɝn ɝaʊnd?

"I only fight when I can't avoid it!" Mat snapped. Blood and bloody ashes, he only fought when he had to. When they trapped him! Why did that seem to happen every time he turned around?

"wʌtɛvɝ jə seɪ, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, teɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz paɪp ən pɔɪntɪŋ ɪɾ ət mæt noʊɪŋli.

"Whatever you say, Mat," Talmanes said, taking out his pipe and pointing it at Mat knowingly.

"bʌt sʌmθɪŋz ɡɑt jə ɑn ɛdʒ. ən ɪɾ ɪzən ðə mɛn wi lɔst."

"But something's got you on edge. And it isn't the men we lost."

fleɪmɪŋ noʊbəlmən. ivən ðə wʌnz jə kəd stænd, laɪk tælmɑnz, ɔlweɪz θɔt ðeɪ nu soʊ mʌtʃ.

Flaming noblemen. Even the ones you could stand, like Talmanes, always thought they knew so much.

ʌv kɔɹs, mæt wɑz naʊ ə noʊbəlmən hɪmsɛlf. doʊn θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. tælmɑnz hæd spɛn ə fju deɪz kɔlɪŋ mæt "jɔɹ haɪnəs" əntɪl mæt hæd lɔst ɪz tɛmpɝ ən jɛld ət ðə mæn  - kɛɹhinɪn kəd bi sətʃ stɪklɝz fəɹ ɹæŋk.

Of course, Mat was now a nobleman himself. Don't think about that, he told himself. Talmanes had spent a few days calling Mat "Your Highness" until Mat had lost his temper and yelled at the man  - Cairhienin could be such sticklers for rank.

wən mæt hæd fɝst ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ ɪz mɛɹɪdʒ tə tuɑn mɛnt, hid læft, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ðə læftɝ ʌv ɪnkɹɛdʒələs peɪn. ən mɛn kɔld ɪm lʌki. wɛl waɪ kʊdn ɪz lʌk əv hɛlpt ɪm əvɔɪd ðɪs feɪt! blʌɾi pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz? wʌd ðət min?

When Mat had first realized what his marriage to Tuon meant, he'd laughed, but it had been the laughter of incredulous pain. And men called him lucky. Well why couldn't his luck have helped him avoid this fate! Bloody Prince of the Ravens? What did that mean?

wɛl, ɹaɪt naʊ hi hæd tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪz mɛn. hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, lʊkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹæŋks ə kævəlɹimən, wɪð kɹɔsboʊmən ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. ðəɹ wɝ θaʊzənz ə boʊθ, ðoʊ mæt hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðɛɹ bænɝz stoʊd. ðeɪ wɝn laɪkli tə pæs mɛni tʃɹævəlɝz ɑn ðɪs bækwɔɾɝ pæθ, bʌɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn dɪd si ðɛm, hi dɪdnt wɑn ðɛɹ tʌŋz wæɡɪŋ.

Well, right now he had to worry about his men. He glanced over his shoulder, looking along the ranks of cavalrymen, with crossbowmen riding behind. There were thousands of both, though Mat had ordered their banners stowed. They weren't likely to pass many travelers on this backwater path, but if anyone did see them, he didn't want their tongues wagging.

wəd ðə sintʃæn tʃeɪs hɪm? hi ən tuɑn boʊθ nu ðeɪ wɝ ɑn əpoʊzɪŋ saɪdz naʊ, ən ʃid sin wʌɾ ɪz ɑɹmi kəd du.

Would the Seanchan chase him? He and Tuon both knew they were on opposing sides now, and she'd seen what his army could do.

dɪd ʃi lʌv hɪm? hi wɑz mɛɹid tə hɝ, bʌt sintʃæn dɪdn θɪŋk laɪk ɹɛɡjəlɝ pipəl. ʃid steɪɾ ɪn ɪz pəzɛʃən, ɛndʒjʊɹɪŋ kæptɪvəɾi, nɛvɝ ɹʌnɪŋ. bʌɾ i hæd lɪɾəl daʊt ðət ʃid muv əɡɛnst ɪm ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ɪt bɛs fəɹ əɹ ɛmpaɪɝ.

Did she love him? He was married to her, but Seanchan didn't think like regular people. She'd stayed in his possession, enduring captivity, never running. But he had little doubt that she'd move against him if she thought it best for her empire.

jɛs, ʃid sɛn mɛn æftɝ hɪm, ðoʊ pətɛnʃəl pɝsut dɪdn tʃɹʌbəl ɪm hæf əz mʌtʃ əz ðə wɝi ðət ʃi maɪt nɑt meɪk ɪt bæk tə ɛbu dɑɹ seɪfli. sʌmwʌn hæɾ ɔfɝɾ ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ paɪl ə kɔɪn fəɹ tuɑnz hɛd. ðət sintʃæn tʃɹeɪɾɝ, ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɑɹmi mæt hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd. hæɾ i bɪn wɝkɪŋ əloʊn? wɝ ðəɹ ʌðɝz? wʌt hæd mæt ɹilis tuɑn ɪntu?

Yes, she'd send men after him, though potential pursuit didn't trouble him half as much as the worry that she might not make it back to Ebou Dar safely. Someone had offered a very large pile of coin for Tuon's head. That Seanchan traitor, the leader of the army Mat had destroyed. Had he been working alone? Were there others? What had Mat released Tuon into?

ðə kwɛstʃənz hɔntəd hɪm. "ʃʊɾ aɪ hæv lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ, dʒju θɪŋk?" mæt faʊn hɪmsɛlf æskɪŋ.

The questions haunted him. "Should I have let her go, do you think?" Mat found himself asking.

tælmɑnz ʃɹʌɡd. "ju ɡeɪv jəɹ wɝd, mæt, ən aɪ θɪŋk ðət ɹæðɝ lɑɹdʒ sintʃæn fɛloʊ wɪð ðə dɪtɝmən aɪz ən ðə blæk ɑɹmɝ wʊdn əv ɹiæktəd wɛl ɪf jud tʃɹaɪd tə kip hɝ."

Talmanes shrugged. "You gave your word, Mat, and I think that rather large Seanchan fellow with the determined eyes and the black armor wouldn't have reacted well if you'd tried to keep her."

"ʃi kəd stɪl bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ," mæt sɛd, ɔlmoʊs tə hɪmsɛlf, stɪl lʊkɪŋ bækwɝd. "aɪ ʃʊdn əv lɛɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt. ful wʊmən."

"She could still be in danger," Mat said, almost to himself, still looking backward. "I shouldn't have let her out of my sight. Fool woman."

"mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð ðə paɪp əɡɛn. "aɪm sɝpɹaɪzd ət ju. waɪ, jəɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə saʊn daʊnɹaɪt hʌzbænli."

"Mat," Talmanes said, pointing at him with the pipe again. "I'm surprised at you. Why, you're starting to sound downright husbandly."

ðət ɡeɪv mæt ə stɑɹt. hi twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn ɪn pɪps' sæɾəl. "wʌt wɑz ðæt? wʌt dʌz ðət min?"

That gave Mat a start. He twisted around in Pips' saddle. "What was that? What does that mean?"

"nʌθɪŋ, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd hɝidli. "dʒʌs ðæt, ðə weɪ jəɹ munɪŋ æftɝ hɝ, aɪ - "

"Nothing, Mat," Talmanes said hurriedly. "Just that, the way you're mooning after her, I - "

"aɪm nɑt munɪŋ," mæt snæpt, pʊlɪŋ ðə lɪp ə hɪz hæt daʊn, ðən ədʒʌstɪŋ ɪz skɑɹf. hɪz mədæljən wɑz ə kʌmftəɹbəl weɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. "aɪm dʒʌst wɝid. ðæts ɔl. ʃi noʊz ə lɑɾ əbaʊt ðə bænd, ən ʃi kəd ɡɪv əweɪ əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθs."

"I'm not mooning," Mat snapped, pulling the lip of his hat down, then adjusting his scarf. His medallion was a comfortable weight around his neck. "I'm just worried. That's all. She knows a lot about the Band, and she could give away our strengths."

tælmɑnz ʃɹʌɡd, pʌfɪŋ ɪz paɪp. ðeɪ ɹoʊd fəɹ ə taɪm ɪn saɪləns. ðə paɪn niɾəlz sɔʌɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd, ən mæt əkeɪʒənəli hɝd wɪmənz læftɝ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, wɛɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn ə lɪɾəl klʌstɝ. fəɹ ɔl ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ dɪdn laɪk wʌn ənʌðɝ, ðeɪ juʒəwəli ɡɑɾ əlɔŋ dʒʌs faɪn wən ʌðɝz kəd si ðɛm. bʌt, əz hid sɛd tə tælmɑnz, wɪmən wɝ oʊnli ɛnəmiz wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ əz lɔŋ əz ðəɹ wɑzn ə mæn ɝaʊn tə ɡæŋ ʌp ɑn.

Talmanes shrugged, puffing his pipe. They rode for a time in silence. The pine needles soughed in the wind, and Mat occasionally heard women's laughter from behind, where the Aes Sedai rode in a little cluster. For all the fact that they didn't like one another, they usually got along just fine when others could see them. But, as he'd said to Talmanes, women were only enemies with one another as long as there wasn't a man around to gang up on.

ðə sʌn wɑz mɑɹk baɪ ə bleɪzɪŋ pætʃ ə klaʊdz; mæt hædn sin pjʊɹ sʌnlaɪɾ ɪn deɪz. hi hædn sin tuɑn ɪn əz lɔŋ iðɝ. ðə tu ɪvɛns sim pɛɹɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd. wɑz ðəɹ ə kənɛkʃən?

The sun was marked by a blazing patch of clouds; Mat hadn't seen pure sunlight in days. He hadn't seen Tuon in as long either. The two events seemed paired in his head. Was there a connection?

blʌɾi ful, hi θɔt tə hɪmsɛlf. nɛks jəl stɑɹt θɪŋkɪŋ laɪk hɝ, ɹiɾɪŋ pɔɹtɛns ɪndə ɛvɹi lɪɾəl θɪŋ, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sɪmbəlz ən minɪŋ ɛvɹi taɪm ə ɹæbət ɹʌnz əkɹɔs jəɹ pæθ əɹ ə hɔɹs lɛts wɪnd.

Bloody fool, he thought to himself. Next you'll start thinking like her, reading portents into every little thing, looking for symbols and meaning every time a rabbit runs across your path or a horse lets wind.

ðət kaɪndə fɔɹtʃəntɛlɪŋ wɑz ɔl nɑnsɛns. ðoʊ hi hæd tə ədmɪt, hi naʊ kɹɪnʒd ɛvɹi taɪm i hɝɾ ən aʊl hut twaɪs.

That kind of fortunetelling was all nonsense. Though he had to admit, he now cringed every time he heard an owl hoot twice.

"hæv jə ɛvɝ lʌvd ə wʊmən, tælmɑnz?" mæt faʊn hɪmsɛlf æskɪŋ.

"Have you ever loved a woman, Talmanes?" Mat found himself asking.

"sɛvɹəl," ðə ʃɔɹt mæn ɹɪplaɪd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð paɪp smoʊk kɝlɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

"Several," the short man replied, riding with pipe smoke curling behind him.

"ɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝ mɛɹiɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛm?"

"Ever consider marrying one of them?"

"noʊ, θæŋk ðə laɪt," tælmɑnz sɛd. ðɛn, əpɛɹənli, hi θɔt bɛɾɝ ʌv wʌt hid dʒʌst sɛd. "aɪ min, ɪt wɑzn ɹaɪt fəɹ mi ət ðə taɪm, mæt. bʌɾ aɪm sɝɾən ɪɾəl wɝk aʊt faɪn fəɹ ju."

"No, thank the Light," Talmanes said. Then, apparently, he thought better of what he'd just said. "I mean, it wasn't right for me at the time, Mat. But I'm certain it will work out fine for you."

mæt skaʊld. ɪf tuɑn wɑz gɑnə blʌɾi faɪnəli dɪsaɪd tə ɡoʊ θɹu wɪð ðə mɛɹɪdʒ, kʊdnt ʃi hæv pɪkt ə taɪm wən ʌðɝz kʊdn hɪɹ?

Mat scowled. If Tuon was going to bloody finally decide to go through with the marriage, couldn't she have picked a time when others couldn't hear?

bʌt noʊ. ʃid ɡɔn ən spoʊkən ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðət mɛn mæt hæd bɪn dumd. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɡɹeɪɾ ət kipɪŋ sikɹəts ənlɛs ðoʊz sikɹəts kəɾ ɪn ɛni weɪ ɪmbɛɹəs əɹ ɪnkənvinjəns meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. ðən jə kəd bi sɝɾən ðə nuz wəd spɹɛd θɹu ði ɪntaɪɝ kæmp ɪn ə deɪz taɪm, ən laɪkli bi noʊn θɹi vɪlədʒəz daʊn ðə ɹoʊɾ əz wɛl.

But no. She'd gone and spoken in front of everyone, including the Aes Sedai. That meant Mat had been doomed. Aes Sedai were great at keeping secrets unless those secrets could in any way embarrass or inconvenience Matrim Cauthon. Then you could be certain the news would spread through the entire camp in a day's time, and likely be known three villages down the road as well.

hɪz oʊn blʌɾi mʌðɝ - liɡz ən liɡz əweɪ - hæd pɹɑbli hɝd ðə nuz baɪ naʊ.

His own bloody mother - leagues and leagues away - had probably heard the news by now.

"aɪm nɑt ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ɡæmbəlɪŋ," mæt mʌɾɝd. "ɔɹ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ."

"I'm not giving up gambling," Mat muttered. "Or drinking."

"soʊ aɪ bɪliv juv toʊl mi," tælmɑnz sɛd. "θɹi əɹ fɔɹ taɪmz soʊ fɑɹ. aɪ hæf bɪliv ðəɾ ɪf aɪ wɝ tə pik ɪndə jəɹ tɛn ət naɪt, aɪd faɪn jə mʌmbəlɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ slip. 'aɪm gɑnə kip blʌɾi ɡæmbəlɪŋ! blʌɾi, blʌɾi ɡæmbəlɪŋ ən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ! wɛɹz maɪ blʌɾi dʒɹɪŋk? ɛniwʌn wɑnə ɡæmbəl fəɹ ɪt?' " hi sɛɾ ɪt wɪð ə pɝfəkli stʃɹeɪt feɪs, bʌt wʌns əɡɛn, ðəɹ wɑz ðət hɪn ʌv ə smaɪl ɪn ɪz aɪz, ɪf jə nu dʒʌst wɛɹ tə lʊk.

"So I believe you've told me," Talmanes said. "Three or four times so far. I half believe that if I were to peek into your tent at night, I'd find you mumbling it in your sleep. 'I'm going to keep bloody gambling! Bloody, bloody gambling and drinking! Where's my bloody drink? Anyone want to gamble for it?' " He said it with a perfectly straight face, but once again, there was that hint of a smile in his eyes, if you knew just where to look.

"aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɛvɹiwʌn noʊz," mæt sɛd. "aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniwʌn tə stɑɹt θɪŋkɪŋ aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ sɑf dʒʌs kəz ʌv . . . jə noʊ."

"I just want to make sure everyone knows," Mat said. "I don't want anyone to start thinking I'm getting soft just because of . . . you know."

tælmɑnz ʃɑɾ ɪm ə kənsoʊlɪŋ lʊk. "ju woʊnt ɡoʊ sɑf dʒʌs kəz jə ɡɑt mɛɹid, mæt. waɪ, səm ə ðə ɡɹeɪt kæptənz ðɛmsɛlvz ɑɹ mɛɹid, aɪ bɪliv. dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ ɪz fəɹ sɝɾən, ən ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi. noʊ, jə woʊnt ɡoʊ sɑf kəz jəɹ mɛɹid."

Talmanes shot him a consoling look. "You won't go soft just because you got married, Mat. Why, some of the Great Captains themselves are married, I believe. Davram Bashere is for certain, and Rodel Ituralde. No, you won't go soft because you're married."

mæt nɑɾəd ʃɑɹpli. ɡʊd ðət wɑz sɛɾəld.

Mat nodded sharply. Good that was settled.

"ju maɪt ɡoʊ bɔɹɪŋ ðoʊ," tælmɑnz noʊɾəd.

"You might go boring though," Talmanes noted.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ðæts ɪt," mæt dɪklɛɹd. "nɛks vɪlədʒ wi faɪnd, wɝ gɑnə ɡoʊ dɪsɪŋ ət ðə tævɝn.

"All right, that's it," Mat declared. "Next village we find, we're going to go dicing at the tavern.

jə ən mi."

You and me."

tælmɑnz ɡɹɪməst. "wɪð ðə kaɪndə θɝd-ɹeɪt waɪn ðiz lɪɾəl maʊntən vɪlədʒəz hæv? pliz, mæt. nɛks jəl bi wɑntɪŋ mi tə dʒɹɪŋk eɪl."

Talmanes grimaced. "With the kind of third-rate wine these little mountain villages have? Please, Mat. Next you'll be wanting me to drink ale."

"noʊ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ." mæt ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əz i hɝd fəmɪljɝ vɔɪsəz. oʊlvɝ - ɪɹz stɪkɪŋ aʊt tə ðə saɪdz, dɪmɪnjəɾɪv feɪs əz ʌɡli əz ɛni mæt hæd sin - sæɾ əstʃɹaɪd wɪnd, tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð noʊl, hu ɹoʊd bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɑn ə boʊni ɡɛldɪŋ. ðə nɑɹld oʊl mæn wɑz nɑɾɪŋ əpɹiʃieɪɾɪvli tə wʌɾ oʊlvɝ wɑz seɪɪŋ. ðə lɪɾəl bɔɪ lʊkt əstɑnɪʃɪŋli sɑləm, ən wɑz əndaʊɾɪdli ɪkspleɪnɪŋ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ ə hɪz θɪɹiz ɑn haʊ tə bɛst snik ɪndə ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ.

"No arguing." Mat glanced over his shoulder as he heard familiar voices. Olver - ears sticking out to the sides, diminutive face as ugly as any Mat had seen - sat astride Wind, chatting with Noal, who rode beside him on a bony gelding. The gnarled old man was nodding appreciatively to what Olver was saying. The little boy looked astonishingly solemn, and was undoubtedly explaining yet another of his theories on how to best sneak into the Tower of Ghenjei.

"hoʊ, naʊ," tælmɑnz sɛd. "ðɛɹz veɪnɪn."

"Ho, now," Talmanes said. "There's Vanin."

mæt tɝn tə spɑɾ ə ɹaɪɾɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɑki pæθ əhɛd. veɪnɪn ɔlweɪz lʊk soʊ ɹɪdɪkjələs, pɝtʃt laɪk ə mɛlən ətɑp ðə bæk ə hɪz hɔɹs, hɪz fit stɪkɪŋ aʊt tə ðə saɪdz. bʌt ðə mæn kəd ɹaɪd, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾɪŋ ðæt.

Mat turned to spot a rider approaching along the rocky path ahead. Vanin always looked so ridiculous, perched like a melon atop the back of his horse, his feet sticking out to the sides. But the man could ride, there was no doubting that.

"ɪɾ ɪz maʊn sɑɹɾələn," veɪnɪn pɹoʊkleɪmd əz i ɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ðɛm, waɪpɪŋ ɪz swɛɾi, bɔldɪŋ bɹaʊ.

"It is Mount Sardlen," Vanin proclaimed as he rode up to them, wiping his sweaty, balding brow.

"ðə vɪlədʒ ɪz dʒʌst əhɛd; ɪts kɔl hɪndɝstæp ɑn ðə mæp. ðiz ɑɹ blʌɾi ɡʊd mæps," hi æɾəd ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli.

"The village is just ahead; it's called Hinderstap on the map. These are bloody good maps," he added grudgingly.

mæt ɛksheɪld ɪn ɹɪlif. hid bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk ðət ðeɪ maɪɾ ɛn ʌp wɑndɝɪŋ ðiz maʊntənz əntɪl ðə læs bæɾəl keɪm ən wɛnt. "ɡɹeɪt," hi bɪɡæn, "wi kən - "

Mat exhaled in relief. He'd begun to think that they might end up wandering these mountains until the Last Battle came and went. "Great," he began, "we can - "

"ə vɪlədʒ?" ə kɝt fimeɪl vɔɪs dɪmændəd.

"A village?" a curt female voice demanded.

mæt tɝnd wɪð ə saɪ əz θɹi ɹaɪɾɝz fɔɹs ðɛɹ weɪ ʌp tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kɑləm. tælmɑnz ɹɪlʌktənli ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə ðə soʊlʒɝz bɪhaɪnd, hɔltɪŋ ðə mɑɹtʃ əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪsɛndəɾ ɑn pʊɹ veɪnɪn. ðə ɹoʊtʌn mæn skwɑɾɪd daʊn ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld əz ðoʊ hid ɹæðɝ əv bɪn dɪskʌvɝd stilɪŋ hɔɹsəz - ən ðɛɹfɔɹ ɑn ɪz weɪ tə ɛksəkjuʃən - ðən əv tə sɪt ðəɹ ən bi ɪntɛɹəɡeɪɾɪd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Mat turned with a sigh as three riders forced their way up to the front of the column. Talmanes reluctantly raised a hand to the soldiers behind, halting the march as the Aes Sedai descended on poor Vanin. The rotund man squatted down in his saddle, looking for all the world as though he'd rather have been discovered stealing horses - and therefore on his way to execution - than have to sit there and be interrogated by Aes Sedai.

dʒoʊlin lɛd ðə pæk. wʌns, mæt maɪɾ əv dɪskɹaɪbd əɹ əz ə pɹɪɾi ɡɝl, wɪð əɹ slɛndɝ fɪɡjɝ ən lɑɹdʒ, ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ bɹaʊn aɪz. bʌt ðəɾ eɪdʒləs ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs wɑz ən ɪnstənt wɔɹnɪŋ fəɹ ɪm naʊ.

Joline led the pack. Once, Mat might have described her as a pretty girl, with her slender figure and large, inviting brown eyes. But that ageless Aes Sedai face was an instant warning for him now.

noʊ, hi wʊdn dɛɹ θɪŋk ə ðə ɡɹin əz pɹɪɾi naʊ. bɪɡɪn lɛɾɪŋ jɝsɛlf θɪŋk ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ əz pɹɪɾi, ən ɪn tu klɪks ə ðə tʌŋ jud faɪn jɝsɛlf ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ fɪŋɡɝ ən hɑpɪŋ əɾ əɹ kəmænd. waɪ, dʒoʊlin hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hɪntəd ðət ʃid laɪk tə hæv mæt əz ə wɔɹɾɝ!

No, he wouldn't dare think of the Green as pretty now. Begin letting yourself think of Aes Sedai as pretty, and in two clicks of the tongue you'd find yourself wrapped around her finger and hopping at her command. Why, Joline had already hinted that she'd like to have Mat as a Warder!

wɑz ʃi stɪl sɔɹ əɾ ɪm kəz hid pæɾəld hɝ? ʃi kʊdn hɝɾ ɪm wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ʌv kɔɹs - ivən wɪθaʊɾ ɪz mədæljən, sɪns ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ swɔɹn nɑt tə juz ðə paʊɝ tə kɪl ɪksɛpt ɪn vɛɹi spəsɪfɪk ɪnstənsəz. bʌɾ i wɑz noʊ ful. hid noʊɾəst ðət ðoʊz oʊðz ə ðɛɹz dɪdn seɪ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt juzɪŋ naɪvz.

Was she still sore at him because he'd paddled her? She couldn't hurt him with the Power, of course - even without his medallion, since Aes Sedai were sworn not to use the Power to kill except in very specific instances. But he was no fool. He'd noticed that those oaths of theirs didn't say anything about using knives.

ðə tu wɪð dʒoʊlin wɝ idɛzinə, ʌv ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, ən tɛslɪn, ʌv ðə ɹɛd. idɛzinə wɑz plɛzən ɪnʌf tə lʊk æt, seɪv fəɹ ðəɾ eɪdʒləs feɪs, bʌt tɛslɪn wɑz əbaʊɾ əz æpɪtaɪzɪŋ əz ə stɪk.

The two with Joline were Edesina, of the Yellow Ajah, and Teslyn, of the Red. Edesina was pleasant enough to look at, save for that ageless face, but Teslyn was about as appetizing as a stick.

ʃɑɹp ə feɪs, ði ɪliɑnɝ wʊmən wɑz boʊni ən skɹæpi, laɪk ən eɪdʒɪd kæt lɛf tu lɔŋ ɑn ɪts oʊn. bʌt ʃi sim tə hæv ə ɡʊd hɛɾ ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, fɹəm wʌt mæt hæd sin, ən hid faʊn əɹ tʃɹiɾɪŋ ɪm wɪð səm mɛʒɝ ə ɹɪspɛk səmtaɪmz. ɹɪspɛk fɹəm ə ɹɛd. ɪmædʒən ðæt.

Sharp of face, the Illianer woman was bony and scrappy, like an aged cat left too long on its own. But she seemed to have a good head on her shoulders, from what Mat had seen, and he'd found her treating him with some measure of respect sometimes. Respect from a Red. Imagine that.

stɪl, fɹəm ðə weɪ itʃ ə ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊkt ət mæt ɪn tɝn əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə fɹʌn ə ðə laɪn, jud nɛvɝ noʊ ðət ðeɪ oʊɾ ɪm ðɛɹ laɪvz. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ ʌv ɪt wɪð wɪmən. seɪv əɹ laɪf, ən ʃiɾ ɪnɛvəɾəbli kleɪm ðət ʃid bɪn əbaʊt tə ɪskeɪp ɑn əɹ oʊn, ən ðɛɹfɔɹ oʊd jə nʌθɪŋ. hæf ðə taɪm, ʃid bɪɹeɪt jə fəɹ mɛsɪŋ ʌp əɹ səpoʊz plænz.

Still, from the way each of those Aes Sedai looked at Mat in turn as they reached the front of the line, you'd never know that they owed him their lives. That was the way of it with women. Save her life, and she'd inevitably claim that she'd been about to escape on her own, and therefore owed you nothing. Half the time, she'd berate you for messing up her supposed plans.

waɪ dɪɾ i bɑðɝ? wʌn ə ðiz deɪz, bɝn hɪm, hi wɑz gɑnə ɡɛt smɑɹɾ ən liv ðə nɛks lɑt kɹaɪɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ tʃeɪnz.

Why did he bother? One of these days, burn him, he was going to get smart and leave the next lot crying in their chains.

"wʌt wɑz ðɪs?" dʒoʊlin dɪmændəɾ ə veɪnɪn. "juv faɪnəli dɪtɝmənd wɛɹ wi ɑɹ?"

"What was this?" Joline demanded of Vanin. "You've finally determined where we are?"

"blʌɾi wɛl hæv," veɪnɪn sɛd, ðən ʌnəbæʃɪdli skɹætʃt hɪmsɛlf. ɡʊd mæn, veɪnɪn. mæt smaɪld. tʃɹiɾəd ɔl pipəl ðə seɪm, veɪnɪn dɪd. ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɔl.

"Bloody well have," Vanin said, then unabashedly scratched himself. Good man, Vanin. Mat smiled. Treated all people the same, Vanin did. Aes Sedai and all.

dʒoʊlin stɛɹd veɪnɪn stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ði aɪz, lumɪŋ laɪk ə ɡɑɹɡɔɪl ətɑp səm lɔɹdz mænʃən stoʊnwɝk. veɪnɪn æktʃəli  kɹɪnʒd, ðən wɪltɪd, ðən faɪnəli lʊk daʊnwɝd, əbæʃt. "aɪ min, aɪ hæv ɪndid, dʒoʊlin sədaɪ."

Joline stared Vanin straight in the eyes, looming like a gargoyle atop some lord's mansion stonework. Vanin actually cringed, then wilted, then finally looked downward, abashed. "I mean, I have indeed, Joline Sedai."

mæt fɛlt ɪz smaɪl feɪd. bɝn ɪɾ ɔl, veɪnɪn!

Mat felt his smile fade. Burn it all, Vanin!

"ɛksələnt," dʒoʊlin sɛd. "æn ðəɹ ɪz ə vɪlədʒ əhɛd, aɪ hɝd? faɪnəli, pɝhæps, wɪl faɪn ə disən ɪn. aɪ kəd juz sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ðə 'fɛɹ' ðiz ɹʌfaɪənz ə kɔθənz kɔl fud."

"Excellent," Joline said. "And there is a village ahead, I heard? Finally, perhaps, we'll find a decent inn. I could use something other than the 'fare' these ruffians of Cauthon's call food."

"hɪɹ naʊ," mæt sɛd, "ðæɾ ɪzənt - "

"Here now," Mat said, "that isn't - "

"haʊ fɑɹ də wi bi fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn, mæstɝ kɔθən?" tɛslɪn kʌɾ ɪn. ʃi dɪɾ əɹ bɛs tə ɪɡnɔɹ dʒoʊlin. ðə tu ʌv əm simd ət wʌn ənʌðɝz θɹoʊts leɪtli - ɪn ðə moʊs kul-feɪst ən aʊtwɝdli eɪmiəbəl ʌv weɪz, ʌv kɔɹs. ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪdn skwɑbəl. hid ɡɑɾən ə tɔkɪŋ tə wʌns fəɹ kɔlɪŋ ðɛɹ "dɪskʌʃənz" "skwɑbəlz." nɛvɝ maɪn ðət mæt hæd sɪstɝz, ən nu wʌɾ ə ɡʊd skwɑbəl saʊndəd laɪk.

"How far do we be from Caemlyn, Master Cauthon?" Teslyn cut in. She did her best to ignore Joline. The two of them seemed at one another's throats lately - in the most cool-faced and outwardly amiable of ways, of course. Aes Sedai didn't squabble. He'd gotten a talking to once for calling their "discussions" "squabbles." Never mind that Mat had sisters, and knew what a good squabble sounded like.

"wʌt dɪd jə seɪ ɝliɝ, veɪnɪn?" mæt æskt, lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "ðæt wɝ əbaʊt tu hʌnʒɹəd liɡz fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn?"

"What did you say earlier, Vanin?" Mat asked, looking at him. "That we're about two hundred leagues from Caemlyn?"

veɪnɪn nɑɾəd. ðə plæn wɑz tə hɛd fəɹ keɪɛmlɪn fɝst, əz i niɾəd tə miɾ ʌp wɪð ɛstin ən dɝəɾ ən sɪkjʊɹ niɾəd ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ən səplaɪz. æftɝ ðæt, hi kəd meɪk ɡʊɾ ɑn ɪz pɹɑməs tə tɑm. ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ wəɾ əv tə weɪɾ ə fju mɔɹ wiks.

Vanin nodded. The plan was to head for Caemlyn first, as he needed to meet up with Estean and Daerid and secure needed information and supplies. After that, he could make good on his promise to Thom. The Tower of Ghenjei would have to wait a few more weeks.

"tu hʌnʒɹəd liɡz," tɛslɪn sɛd. "haʊ lɔŋ əntɪl wi ɝaɪv, ðɛn?"

"Two hundred leagues," Teslyn said. "How long until we arrive, then?"

"wɛl, aɪ ɡɛs ðət dɪpɛnz," veɪnɪn sɛd. "aɪ kəd pɹɑbli meɪk tu hʌnʒɹəd liɡz ɪn ə lɪɾəl oʊvɝ ə wik, ɪf aɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ əloʊn, wɪð ə kʌpəl ʌv ɡʊd hɔɹsəz tə ɹaɪɾ ɪn ʃɪfs ən wɑz kɹɔsɪŋ fəmɪljɝ tɝeɪn. ðə hoʊl ɑɹmi, ðoʊ, θɹu ðiz hɪlz juzɪŋ ə bɹoʊkən ɹoʊdweɪ? twɛnti deɪz, aɪd seɪ. meɪbi lɔŋɡɝ."

"Well, I guess that depends," Vanin said. "I could probably make two hundred leagues in a little over a week, if I were going alone, with a couple of good horses to ride in shifts and was crossing familiar terrain. The whole army, though, through these hills using a broken roadway? Twenty days, I'd say. Maybe longer."

dʒoʊlin ɡlænst ət mæt.

Joline glanced at Mat.

"wi ɑɹən livɪŋ ðə bæn bɪhaɪnd," mæt sɛd. "nɑɾ ən ɑpʃən, dʒoʊlin."

"We aren't leaving the Band behind," Mat said. "Not an option, Joline."

ʃi lʊkt əweɪ, hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən dɪsæɾəsfaɪd.

She looked away, her expression dissatisfied.

"jɔɹ wɛlkəm tə ɡoʊ ɑn jəɹ oʊn," mæt sɛd. "ðæt ɡoʊz fəɹ itʃ ə ju. jə ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹən maɪ pɹɪznɝz; liv ɛni taɪm jə wɑnt, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə hɛd nɔɹθ. aɪ woʊn ɹɪsk jə hɛɾɪŋ bæk tə bi teɪkən baɪ sintʃæn."

"You're welcome to go on your own," Mat said. "That goes for each of you. You Aes Sedai aren't my prisoners; leave any time you want, so long as you head north. I won't risk you heading back to be taken by Seanchan."

wʌt wəɾ ɪt bi laɪk, tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð dʒʌs ðə bæn əɡɛn, nɑɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn saɪt? ɑ, ɪf oʊnli.

What would it be like, traveling with just the Band again, not an Aes Sedai in sight? Ah, if only.

tɛslɪn lʊk θɔtfəl. dʒoʊlin ɡlænst ət hɝ, bʌt ðə ɹɛd dɪdnt ɡɪv ɛni ɪndəkeɪʃən ɪf ʃid bi wɪlɪŋ tə liv əɹ nɑt. idɛzinə, haʊɛvɝ, hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd tə dʒoʊlin. ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ.

Teslyn looked thoughtful. Joline glanced at her, but the Red didn't give any indication if she'd be willing to leave or not. Edesina, however, hesitated, then nodded to Joline. She was willing.

"vɛɹi wɛl," dʒoʊlin sɛd tə mæt wɪð ə hɔɾi ɛɹ. "ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd tə bi əweɪ fɹəm jəɹ kɹudnəs, kɔθən. pɹipɛɹ fəɹ ʌs, seɪ, twɛnti-fɔɹ maʊns ən wi ʃæl bi ɔf."

"Very well," Joline said to Mat with a haughty air. "It would be good to be away from your crudeness, Cauthon. Prepare for us, say, twenty-four mounts and we shall be off."

"twɛnti-fɔɹ? " mæt æskt.

"Twenty-four? " Mat asked.

"jɛs," dʒoʊlin sɛd. "jɔɹ mæn hɪɹ mɛnʃən ðət hid nid tu hɔɹsəz tə meɪk ðə tʃɹɪp ɪn ə ɹizənəbəl əmaʊn ə taɪm. soʊ ðəɾ i kəd ɹimaʊnt, pɹəzuməbli, wən wʌn ə ðə bists ɡɹu taɪɝd."

"Yes," Joline said. "Your man here mentioned that he'd need two horses to make the trip in a reasonable amount of time. So that he could remount, presumably, when one of the beasts grew tired."

"aɪ kaʊn tu ʌv ju," mæt sɛd, hɪz æŋɡɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ. "ðæt minz fɔɹ hɔɹsəz. aɪ fɪɡjɝd jud bi smɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə də ðət mæθ, dʒoʊlin." ən ðɛn, sɑftɝ, hi æɾəd, "ɪf dʒʌs bɛɹli."

"I count two of you," Mat said, his anger rising. "That means four horses. I figured you'd be smart enough to do that math, Joline." And then, softer, he added, "If just barely."

dʒoʊlinz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, ən idɛzinəz ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz peɪntəd wɪð ʃɑk. tɛslɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə ʃɑkt ɡlæns, simɪŋ dɪsəpɔɪntɪd. tə ðə saɪd, tælmɑnz dʒʌs loʊɝɾ ɪz paɪp ən wɪsəl kwaɪətli.

Joline's eyes opened wide, and Edesina's expression was painted with shock. Teslyn gave him a shocked glance, seeming disappointed. To the side, Talmanes just lowered his pipe and whistled quietly.

"ðæt mədæljən ə jʊɹz meɪks jə ɪmpjəɾənt, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," dʒoʊlin sɛd koʊldli.

"That medallion of yours makes you impudent, Matrim Cauthon," Joline said coldly.

"maɪ maʊð meɪks mi ɪmpjəɾənt, dʒoʊlin," mæt ɹɪplaɪd wɪð ə saɪ, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə mədæljən hɪɾən bɪniθ ɪz lusli taɪd ʃɝt. "ðə mədæljən dʒʌs meɪks mi tʃɹuθfəl. aɪ bɪliv jə wɝ gɑnə ɪkspleɪn waɪ jə nid tə teɪk twɛnti-fɔɹ ə maɪ hɔɹsəz wən aɪ bɛɹli hæv ɪnʌf fəɹ maɪ mɛn əz ɪɾ ɪz?"

"My mouth makes me impudent, Joline," Mat replied with a sigh, fingering the medallion hidden beneath his loosely tied shirt. "The medallion just makes me truthful. I believe you were going to explain why you need to take twenty-four of my horses when I barely have enough for my men as it is?"

"tu itʃ fəɹ idɛzinə, mi, ən maɪ wɔɹɾɝz," dʒoʊlin sɛd stɪfli. "tu itʃ fəɹ ðə fɔɹmɝ sʌldəm. jə doʊn pɹɪzum ðəɾ aɪm gɑnə liv əm bɪhaɪn tə bi kɝʌptɪd baɪ jəɹ lɪɾəl bæn hɪɹ?"

"Two each for Edesina, me, and my Warders," Joline said stiffly. "Two each for the former sul'dam. You don't presume that I'm going to leave them behind to be corrupted by your little band here?"

"tu wɔɹɾɝz ən tu sʌldəm," mæt sɛd. "ðæts twɛlv hɔɹsəz."

"Two Warders and two sul'dam," Mat said. "That's twelve horses."

"tu fəɹ sɛɾəl. aɪ əsum ʃɪl wɑnə bi əweɪ fɹəm ɔl ə ðɪs wɪð ʌs."

"Two for Setalle. I assume she'll want to be away from all of this with us."

"fɔɹtin."

"Fourteen."

"tu mɔɹ fəɹ tɛslɪn," dʒoʊlin sɛd. "ʃi wɪl əndaʊɾɪdli wɑnə ɡoʊ wɪð ʌs, ðoʊ ʃi kɝənli hæz nʌθɪŋ tə seɪ ɑn ðə mæɾɝ. ən wɪl niɾ əbaʊt fɔɹ pæk ænəməlz' wɝθ tə kæɹi əɹ θɪŋz. ðəl əv tə tʃɹeɪd ðɛɹ bɝɾənz tu, soʊ fɔɹ mɔɹ fəɹ ðæt. twɛnti-fɔɹ."

"Two more for Teslyn," Joline said. "She will undoubtedly want to go with us, though she currently has nothing to say on the matter. And we'll need about four pack animals' worth to carry our things. They'll have to trade their burdens too, so four more for that. Twenty-four."

"wɪtʃ jəl fid haʊ?" mæt æskt. "ɪf jəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðət hɑɹd, jə woʊn əv taɪm tə ɡɹeɪz jəɹ hɔɹsəz. ðɛɹz bɛɹli ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ əm tə it ðiz deɪz ɛniweɪ." ðət hæd pɹuvən ə bɪɡ pɹɑbləm; ðə spɹɪŋ ɡɹæs wɑzn kʌmɪŋ ɪn. ðə mɛdoʊz ðeɪ pæst wɝ bɹaʊn wɪð fɔlən livz, ðə dɛd wɪntɝ widz pɹɛs flæt baɪ snoʊ, bɛɹli ə nu ʃuɾ ʌv ɡɹæs əɹ wid. hɔɹsəz kəd fiɾ ɑn ðə dɛd livz ən wɪntɝ ɡɹæs, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt waɪl dɪɹ ən ʌðɝ ænəməlz hæd bɪn æktɪv, iɾɪŋ daʊn wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ kəd faɪnd.

"Which you'll feed how?" Mat asked. "If you're riding that hard, you won't have time to graze your horses. There's barely anything for them to eat these days anyway." That had proven a big problem; the spring grass wasn't coming in. The meadows they passed were brown with fallen leaves, the dead winter weeds pressed flat by snow, barely a new shoot of grass or weed. Horses could feed on the dead leaves and winter grass, of course, but wild deer and other animals had been active, eating down whatever they could find.

ɪf ðə læn dɪdn dɪsaɪd tə stɑɹt blumɪŋ sun . . . wɛl, ðeɪ wɝ ɪn fəɹ ə dɪfəkəl sʌmɝ. bʌt ðət wɑz ənʌðɝ pɹɑbləm ɪntaɪɝli.

If the land didn't decide to start blooming soon . . . well, they were in for a difficult summer. But that was another problem entirely.

"wi wɪl nid jə tə ɡɪv əs fid, ʌv kɔɹs," dʒoʊlin sɛd. "æn səm kɔɪn fəɹ ɪnz. . . ."

"We will need you to give us feed, of course," Joline said. "And some coin for inns. . . ."

"æn u ɪz gɑnə teɪk kɛɹ ʌv ɔl ðoʊz hɔɹsəz? jə gɑnə bɹʌʃ əm daʊn itʃ naɪt, tʃɛk ðɛɹ hʊvz, si ðət ðɛɹ fiɾ ɪz pɹɑpɝli mɛʒɝd?"

"And who is going to take care of all those horses? You going to brush them down each night, check their hooves, see that their feed is properly measured?"

"aɪ səpoʊz wi ʃəd teɪk ə hændfʊl ə jəɹ soʊlʒɝz wɪð ʌs," dʒoʊlin sɛd, saʊndɪŋ dɪsæɾəsfaɪd.

"I suppose we should take a handful of your soldiers with us," Joline said, sounding dissatisfied.

"ə nɛsəsɛɹi ɪnkənvinjəns."

"A necessary inconvenience."

"ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi," mæt sɛd flætli. "ɪz fəɹ maɪ mɛn tə steɪ wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑntəd, nɑt wɛɹ ðəɹ ən ɪnkənvinjəns. noʊ, ðeɪ steɪ - ən jəl əv noʊ kɔɪn fɹəm mi. ɪf jə wɑnə ɡoʊ, jə kən teɪk wʌn hɔɹs itʃ ən ə sɪŋɡəl pækhɔɹs tə kæɹi jəɹ θɪŋz. əl ɡɪv jə səm fid fəɹ ðə pʊɹ bists, ən ɡɪvɪŋ jə ðət mʌtʃ ɪz dʒɛnɝəs."

"The only thing that is necessary," Mat said flatly. "Is for my men to stay where they're wanted, not where they're an inconvenience. No, they stay - and you'll have no coin from me. If you want to go, you can take one horse each and a single packhorse to carry your things. I'll give you some feed for the poor beasts, and giving you that much is generous."

"bʌt wɪð oʊnli wʌn hɔɹs itʃ, wɪl bɛɹli bi fæstɝ ðən ði ɑɹmi!" dʒoʊlin sɛd.

"But with only one horse each, we'll barely be faster than the army!" Joline said.

"ɪmædʒən ðæt," mæt sɛd. hi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. "veɪnɪn, ɡoʊ ən tɛl mændəvwɪn tə pæs ðə wɝd. wɪl bi kæmpɪŋ sun. aɪ noʊ ɪts bɛɹli æftɝnun, bʌɾ aɪ wɑn ðə bæn fɑɹ ɪnʌf fɹəm ðət vɪlədʒ nɑt tə bi θɹɛɾənɪŋ, bʌt kloʊs ɪnʌf ðəɾ ə fju ʌv əs kən ɡoʊ daʊn tə fil θɪŋz aʊt."

"Imagine that," Mat said. He turned away from her. "Vanin, go and tell Mandevwin to pass the word. We'll be camping soon. I know it's barely afternoon, but I want the Band far enough from that village not to be threatening, but close enough that a few of us can go down to feel things out."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," veɪnɪn sɛd, wɪð nʌn ə ðə ɹɪspɛk hid ʃoʊn ðə blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi tɝn ɪz hɔɹs ən bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪd daʊn ðə laɪn.

"All right," Vanin said, with none of the respect he'd shown the bloody Aes Sedai. He turned his horse and began to ride down the line.

"æn veɪnɪn," mæt kɔld. "meɪk ʃʊɹ mændəvwɪn ɪz əwɛɹ ðət wən aɪ seɪ 'ə fju ʌv ʌs' wɪl ɡoʊ daʊn, aɪ min ə vɛɹi smɔl ɡɹup, lɛd baɪ maɪsɛlf ən tælmɑnz. aɪ woʊn əv ðət vɪlədʒ ɪnveɪɾəd baɪ sɛvən θaʊzən soʊlʒɝz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ fʌn! əl baɪ ə kɑɹɾ ɪn ðə taʊn ən wʌɾ eɪl aɪ kən faɪnd, ðən sɛn ɪt bæk fəɹ ðə mɛn. ðəɹ ɪz tə bi stʃɹɪkt ɔɹɾɝ ɪn kæmp, wɪð noʊ wʌn æksədɛntəli wɑndɝɪŋ daʊn tə vɪzət, naʊ. ʌndɝstænd?"

"And Vanin," Mat called. "Make sure Mandevwin is aware that when I say 'a few of us' will go down, I mean a very small group, led by myself and Talmanes. I won't have that village invaded by seven thousand soldiers looking for fun! I'll buy a cart in the town and what ale I can find, then send it back for the men. There is to be strict order in camp, with no one accidentally wandering down to visit, now. Understand?"

veɪnɪn nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ ɡɹɪm. ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ fʌn tə bi ðə wʌn u hæd tə ɪnfɔɹm ðə mɛn ðət ðeɪ wɝn gɑnə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ liv. mæt tɝn bæk tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "wɛl?" hi æskt. "ju teɪkɪŋ maɪ kaɪn ɔfɝ əɹ nɑt?"

Vanin nodded, looking grim. It was never fun to be the one who had to inform the men that they weren't going to be getting leave. Mat turned back to the Aes Sedai. "Well?" he asked. "You taking my kind offer or not?"

dʒoʊlin dʒʌst snɪft, ðən tʃɹɑɾəd əɹ hɔɹs bæk daʊn ðə ɹæŋks, ɑbviəsli tɝnɪŋ daʊn ðə tʃæns tə ɡoʊ əloʊn. pɪɾi, ðæt. ɪt wʊɾə meɪɾ ɪm smaɪl itʃ stɛp ə ðə weɪ tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. ðoʊ, ɪt pɹɑbli wʊɾə teɪkən dʒoʊlin ɔl ə θɹi deɪz tə faɪn səm sæp ɪn ə vɪlədʒ sʌmwɛɹ tə ɡɪv əɹ ɪz hɔɹsəz soʊ ðəɾ əɹ kɹu kəd ɹaɪd fæstɝ.

Joline just sniffed, then trotted her horse back down the ranks, obviously turning down the chance to go alone. Pity, that. It would have made him smile each step of the way to think of it. Though, it probably would have taken Joline all of three days to find some sap in a village somewhere to give her his horses so that her crew could ride faster.

idɛzinə ɹoʊɾ əweɪ, ən tɛslɪn tʃɹeɪld æftɝ, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ mæt wɪð ə kjʊɹiəs ɪkspɹɛʃən. ʃi stɪl lʊk dɪsəpɔɪntɪɾ ɪn ɪm tu. hi ɡlænst əweɪ, ðən fɛlt ənɔɪɾ ət hɪmsɛlf. wʌɾ i kɛɹ wʌt ʃi θɔt?

Edesina rode away, and Teslyn trailed after, regarding Mat with a curious expression. She still looked disappointed in him too. He glanced away, then felt annoyed at himself. What did he care what she thought?

tælmɑnz wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "ðæt wɑz ɑɾ ə ju, mæt," ðə mæn sɛd.

Talmanes was looking at him. "That was odd of you, Mat," the man said.

"wʌt?" mæt sɛd. "ðə ɹistʃɹɪkʃən ɑn ðə mɛn? ðəɹ ə ɡʊd lɑt, ðə bænd, bʌɾ aɪv nɛvɝ noʊn ə ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz u wɝn laɪkli tə ɡɛt ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ə lɪɾəl tʃɹʌbəl naʊ ən ðɛn, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wɛɹ ðɛɹz eɪl tə bi faʊnd."

"What?" Mat said. "The restriction on the men? They're a good lot, the Band, but I've never known a group of soldiers who weren't likely to get themselves in a little trouble now and then, particularly where there's ale to be found."

"aɪ wɑzn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə mɛn, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, bɛndɪŋ tə tæp aʊɾ ɪz paɪp əɡɛnst ɪz stɝəp, dɑɾəl fɔlɪŋ tə flʌɾɝ bæk ɑntu ðə stoʊni ɹoʊdweɪ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz hɔɹs. "aɪm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ jə tʃɹiɾəd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. laɪt, mæt, wi cʊɾə bɪn ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm! aɪd kaʊn twɛnti-fɔɹ hɔɹsəz ən səm kɔɪn ə bɑɹɡən tə bi fɹi ʌv tu ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"I wasn't talking about the men, Mat," Talmanes said, bending to tap out his pipe against his stirrup, dottle falling to flutter back onto the stony roadway beside his horse. "I'm talking about how you treated the Aes Sedai. Light, Mat, we could have been rid of them! I'd count twenty-four horses and some coin a bargain to be free of two Aes Sedai."

"aɪ woʊn bi ʃʌvd ɝaʊnd," mæt sɛd stʌbɝnli, weɪvɪŋ fəɹ ðə bæn tə bɪɡɪn ɪts mɑɹtʃ əɡɛn.

"I won't be shoved around," Mat said stubbornly, waving for the Band to begin its march again.

"nɑɾ ivən tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə dʒoʊlin. ɪf ʃi wɑns sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm mi, lɛɾ əɹ æsk wɪð ə ɡɹeɪn ə pəlaɪtnəs, ɹæðɝ ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bʊli mi ɪndə ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑns. ɪm noʊ læp dɔɡ." bɝn ɪt, hi wɑznt!

"Not even to get rid of Joline. If she wants something from me, let her ask with a grain of politeness, rather than trying to bully me into giving her whatever she wants. I'm no lap dog." Burn it, he wasn't!

ən i wɑzn hʌzbænli iðɝ, wʌtɛvɝ ðət mɛnt.

And he wasn't husbandly either, whatever that meant.

"ju ɹɪli də mɪs hɝ," tælmɑnz sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ə lɪɾəl sɝpɹaɪzd əz ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz fɛl ɪndə peɪs bɪsaɪd wʌn ənʌðɝ.

"You really do miss her," Talmanes said, sounding a little surprised as their horses fell into pace beside one another.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə blæðɝɪŋ əbaʊt naʊ?"

"What are you blathering about now?"

"mæt, jə ɑɹ nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ðə moʊst ɹəfaɪn ə mɛn, əl ədmɪt. səmtaɪmz jəɹ hjumɝ ɪz ɪndiɾ ə bɪt ɹaɪp ən jəɹ toʊn ɑn ðə bɹʌsk saɪd. bʌt jə ɑɹ ɹɛɹli daʊnɹaɪt ɹud, nɔɹ ɪntɛnʃənəli ɪnsʌltɪŋ. jə ɹɪli ɑɹ ɑn ɛdʒ, ɑɹən ju?"

"Mat, you are not always the most refined of men, I'll admit. Sometimes your humor is indeed a bit ripe and your tone on the brusque side. But you are rarely downright rude, nor intentionally insulting. You really are on edge, aren't you?"

mæt sɛd nʌθɪŋ, dʒʌs pʊl ðə bɹɪm ə hɪz hæt daʊn əɡɛn.

Mat said nothing, just pulled the brim of his hat down again.

"aɪm ʃʊɹ ðət ʃɪl bi faɪn, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, toʊn dʒɛnlɝ. "ʃi ɪz ɹɔɪəlti. ðeɪ noʊ haʊ tə teɪk kɛɹ ə ðɛmsɛlvz. ən ʃiz ɡɑt ðoʊz soʊlʒɝz wɑtʃɪŋ æftɝ hɝ. nɑt tə mɛnʃən oʊɡiɝ. oʊɡiɝ wɔɹiɝz! hu wəd θɪŋk ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ? ʃɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt."

"I'm sure that she will be fine, Mat," Talmanes said, tone gentler. "She is royalty. They know how to take care of themselves. And she's got those soldiers watching after her. Not to mention Ogier. Ogier warriors! Who would think of such a thing? She'll be all right."

"wɝ dʌn wɪð ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən," mæt sɛd, ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ tə hoʊld ɪɾ əpɹaɪt, kɝv bleɪd təwɔɹd ði ənsin sʌn əbʌv, bʌɾ ɪn ðə lænsɝz stʃɹæp ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz sæɾəl.

"We're done with this conversation," Mat said, shifting his spear to hold it upright, curved blade toward the unseen sun above, butt in the lancer's strap at the side of his saddle.

"aɪ dʒʌst - "

"I just - "

"oʊvɝ," mæt sɛd. "ju doʊn əv ɛni mɔɹ ə ðət təbæk, də ju?"

"Over," Mat said. "You don't have any more of that tabac, do you?"

tælmɑnz saɪd. "ɪt wɑz ðə læs pɪntʃ. ɡʊd təbæk - tu ɹɪvɝz ɡɹoʊn. ði oʊnli paʊtʃ ʌv ɪɾ aɪv sin ɪn səm taɪm. ɪt wɑz ə ɡɪft fɹəm kɪŋ ɹɔdʒɹən, əlɔŋ wɪð ðə paɪp."

Talmanes sighed. "It was the last pinch. Good tabac - Two Rivers grown. The only pouch of it I've seen in some time. It was a gift from King Roedran, along with the pipe."

"hi mʌst əv væljud ju."

"He must have valued you."

"ɪt wɑz ɡʊd, ɑnəst wɝk," tælmɑnz sɛd. "æn tɛɹəbli bɔɹɪŋ. nɑt laɪk ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ju, mæt.

"It was good, honest work," Talmanes said. "And terribly boring. Not like riding with you, Mat.

ɪts ɡʊd tə hæv jə bæk, kɹʌst ən ɔl. bʌt jəɹ tɔk ə fid wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dʌz əv mi wɝid."

It's good to have you back, crust and all. But your talk of feed with the Aes Sedai does have me worried."

mæt nɑɾəd. "haʊ ɑɹ wi ɑn ɹæʃənz?"

Mat nodded. "How are we on rations?"

"loʊ," tælmɑnz sɛd.

"Low," Talmanes said.

"wil baɪ wʌt wi kən ət ðə vɪlədʒ," mæt sɛd. "wiv ɡɑt kɔɪn kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ ɪɹz, æftɝ wʌt ɹɔdʒɹən ɡeɪv ju."

"We'll buy what we can at the village," Mat said. "We've got coin coming out our ears, after what Roedran gave you."

ə smɔl vɪlədʒ wɑzn laɪkli tə hæv ɪnʌf tə səplaɪ ðə hoʊl ɑɹmi. bʌt, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə mæps, ðeɪd sun bi ɛntɝɪŋ mɔɹ pɑpjəleɪɾəd lænz. jud pæs ə vɪlədʒ əɹ tu ɛvɹi deɪ ɪn ðoʊz ɛɹiəz, tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ə kwɪk fɔɹs laɪk ðə bænd. tə steɪ əfloʊt, jə skævənʒd ən bɑt wʌtɛvɝ lɪɾəl bɪt jə kəɾ əɾ itʃ vɪlədʒ jə pæst. ə wæɡoʊnloʊd hɪɹ, ə kɑɹtfəl ðɛɹ, ə bʌkəɾ əɹ tu ʌv æpəlz fɹəm ə pæsɪŋ fɑɹmstɛd. sɛvən θaʊzən mɛn wɑz ə lɑt tə fid, bʌɾ ə ɡʊd kəmændɝ nu nɑt tə tɝn daʊn ivən ə hændfʊl ʌv ɡɹeɪn. ɪɾ æɾəd ʌp.

A small village wasn't likely to have enough to supply the whole army. But, according to the maps, they'd soon be entering more populated lands. You'd pass a village or two every day in those areas, traveling with a quick force like the Band. To stay afloat, you scavenged and bought whatever little bit you could at each village you passed. A wagonload here, a cartful there, a bucket or two of apples from a passing farmstead. Seven thousand men was a lot to feed, but a good commander knew not to turn down even a handful of grain. It added up.

"jɛs, bʌt wɪl ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz sɛl?" tælmɑnz æskt. "ɑn əɹ weɪ daʊn tə mit ju, wi hæɾ ə sævədʒ taɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn tə sɛl əs fud. simz ðəɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ tə bi faʊn ðiz deɪz. fuɾ ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ skɛɹs, noʊ mæɾɝ wɛɹ jə ɡoʊ ən noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mʌtʃ mʌni jə hæv."

"Yes, but will the villagers sell?" Talmanes asked. "On our way down to meet you, we had a savage time getting anyone to sell us food. Seems there isn't much to be found these days. Food is getting scarce, no matter where you go and no matter how much money you have."

blʌɾi pɝfəkt. mæt ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ, ðən ɡɹu ənɔɪɾ ət hɪmsɛlf fəɹ duɪŋ soʊ. wɛl, meɪbi hi wɑz ə lɪɾəl ɑn ɛdʒ. nɑt kəz ə tuɑn, ðoʊ.

Bloody perfect. Mat ground his teeth, then grew annoyed at himself for doing so. Well, maybe he was a little on edge. Not because of Tuon, though.

iðɝ weɪ, hi niɾəd tə ɹɪlæks. ən ðət vɪlədʒ əhɛd - wʌt hæd veɪnɪn kɔld ɪt? hɪndɝstæp?

Either way, he needed to relax. And that village ahead - what had Vanin called it? Hinderstap?

"haʊ mʌtʃ kɔɪn juv ɑn ju?"

"How much coin do you have on you?"

tælmɑnz fɹaʊnd. "kʌpəl ʌv ɡoʊl mɑɹks, paʊtʃ fʊl ə sɪlvɝ kɹaʊnz. waɪ?"

Talmanes frowned. "Couple of gold marks, pouch full of silver crowns. Why?"

"nɑɾ ɪnʌf," mæt sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "wil əv tə dɪɡ səm mɔɹ aʊɾ ə maɪ pɝsənəl tʃɛs fɝst. meɪbi bɹɪŋ ðə hoʊl θɪŋ." hi tɝn pɪps ɝaʊnd. "kʌm ɑn."

"Not enough," Mat said, rubbing his chin. "We'll have to dig some more out of my personal chest first. Maybe bring the whole thing." He turned Pips around. "Come on."

"weɪt, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, ɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ən fɑloʊɪŋ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ wi duɪŋ?"

"Wait, Mat," Talmanes said, reining in and following. "What are we doing?"

"jɔɹ gɑnə kaɪnli teɪk mi ʌp ɑn maɪ ɔfɝ tə ɡoʊ ɛndʒɔɪ aʊɝsɛlvz ət ðə tævɝn," mæt sɛd.

"You're going to kindly take me up on my offer to go enjoy ourselves at the tavern," Mat said.

"ænd waɪl wɝ əɾ ɪt, wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɹisəplaɪ. ɪf maɪ lʌks wɪð mi, wɪl də ɪt fəɹ fɹi."

"And while we're at it, we're going to resupply. If my luck's with me, we'll do it for free."

ɪf ɛɡwin əɹ nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn ðɛɹ, ðeɪɾ əv bɑkst ɪz ɪɹz ən toʊld ɪm i wɑz gɑnə də noʊ sətʃ θɪŋ. tuɑn pɹɑbli wʊɾə lʊkt əɾ ɪm kjʊɹiəsli ən ðən sɛd sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm fil ɪz ʃeɪm ɹaɪt daʊn ɪndə hɪz buts.

If Egwene or Nynaeve had been there, they'd have boxed his ears and told him he was going to do no such thing. Tuon probably would have looked at him curiously and then said something that made him feel his shame right down into his boots.

ðə ɡʊd θɪŋ əbaʊt tælmɑnz, haʊɛvɝ, wɑz ðəɾ i sɪmpli spɝɾ ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd, feɪs stoʊɪk, aɪz bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ dʒʌst ə hɪn ʌv əmjuzmənt. "wɛl, aɪv ɡɑt tə si ðɪs, ðɛn!"

The good thing about Talmanes, however, was that he simply spurred his horse forward, face stoic, eyes betraying just a hint of amusement. "Well, I've got to see this, then!"

tʃæptɝ twɛntiwʌn

CHAPTER 21

ɛmbɝz ən æʃ pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən faʊn hɪmsɛlf hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ.

Embers and Ash Perrin opened his eyes and found himself hanging in the air.

hi fɛlt ə spaɪk ə tɛɹɝ, flaʊndɝɪŋ ɪn ðə skaɪ. blæk klaʊdz bɔɪld oʊvɝhɛd, dɑɹk ən ɑmənəs.

He felt a spike of terror, floundering in the sky. Black clouds boiled overhead, dark and ominous.

bɪloʊ, ə pleɪn ʌv waɪl bɹaʊn ɡɹæsəz ɹoʊld ɪn ðə wɪnd, noʊ saɪnz ə hjumənz. noʊ tɛns, noʊ ɹoʊdz, nɑɾ ivən ɛni fʊtpɹɪns.

Below, a plain of wild brown grasses rolled in the wind, no signs of humans. No tents, no roads, not even any footprints.

pɛɹɪn wɑzn fɔlɪŋ. hi dʒʌs hʌŋ ðɛɹ. hi weɪvd ɪz ɑɹmz ɹiflɛksɪvli, əz ɪf tə swɪm, pænɪkɪŋ əz ɪz maɪn tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk sɛns ə ðə dɪsɔɹiənteɪʃən.

Perrin wasn't falling. He just hung there. He waved his arms reflexively, as if to swim, panicking as his mind tried to make sense of the disorientation.

ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, hi θɔt. aɪm ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. aɪ wɛn tə slip, hoʊpɪŋ tə kʌm hɪɹ.

The wolf dream, he thought. I'm in the wolf dream. I went to sleep, hoping to come here.

hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə bɹið ɪn ən aʊɾ ən stɪl ɪz fleɪlɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə bi kɑm waɪl hæŋɪŋ hʌnʒɹədz ə fiɾ ʌp ɪn ðə skaɪ. sʌɾənli, ə ɡɹeɪ-fɝd fɔɹm ʃɑt pæs hɪm, lipɪŋ θɹu ði ɛɹ. ðə wʊlf sɔɹd daʊn tə ðə fil bɪloʊ, lændɪŋ izəli.

He forced himself to breathe in and out and still his flailing, though it was difficult to be calm while hanging hundreds of feet up in the sky. Suddenly, a gray-furred form shot past him, leaping through the air. The wolf soared down to the field below, landing easily.

"hɑpɝ!"

"Hopper!"

dʒʌmp daʊn, jʌŋ bʊl. dʒʌmp. ɪts seɪf. əz ɔlweɪz, ðə sɛndɪŋ fɹəm ðə wʊlf keɪm əz ə mɪkstʃɝ ə sɛns ən ɪmədʒəz. pɛɹɪn wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ bɛɾɝ ən bɛɾɝ əɾ ɪntɝpɹɛɾɪŋ ðoʊz - ðə sɑft ɝθ əz ə ɹɛpɹəzɛnteɪʃən ə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹʌʃɪŋ wɪn əz ən ɪmədʒ ə dʒʌmpɪŋ, ðə sɛn ə ɹilækseɪʃən ən kɑmnəs tə ɪndəkeɪt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə fɪɹ.

Jump down, Young Bull. Jump. It is safe. As always, the Sending from the wolf came as a mixture of scents and images. Perrin was getting better and better at interpreting those - the soft earth as a representation of the ground, rushing wind as an image of jumping, the scent of relaxation and calmness to indicate there was no need to fear.

"bʌt haʊ?"

"But how?"

taɪmz bɪfɔɹ, jə ɔlweɪz ɹʌʃt əhɛd, laɪk ə pʌp nuli wind. dʒʌmp. dʒʌmp daʊn! fɑɹ bɪloʊ, hɑpɝ sæɾ ɑn ɪz hɔntʃɪz ɪn ðə fild, ɡɹɪnɪŋ ʌp ət pɛɹɪn.

Times before, you always rushed ahead, like a pup newly weaned. Jump. Jump down! Far below, Hopper sat on his haunches in the field, grinning up at Perrin.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ ən mʌɾɝd ə kɝs əɹ tu fəɹ stʌbɝn wʊlvz. ɪt sim tə hɪm ðət ðə dɛd wʌnz wɝ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli bʊlhɛɾɪd. ðoʊ hɑpɝ dɪɾ əv ə pɔɪnt. pɛɹɪn hæd lɛp bɪfɔɹ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, ɪf nɛvɝ fɹəm ðə skaɪ ɪtsɛlf.

Perrin ground his teeth and muttered a curse or two for stubborn wolves. It seemed to him that the dead ones were particularly bullheaded. Though Hopper did have a point. Perrin had leaped before in this place, if never from the sky itself.

hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən kloʊzd ɪz aɪz ən ɪmædʒən hɪmsɛlf dʒʌmpɪŋ. ɛɹ ɹʌʃt ɝaʊn ɪm ɪn ə sʌɾən bɝst, bʌt ðən ɪz fit hɪt sɑft ɡɹaʊnd. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz. ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹeɪ wʊlf, skɑɹd fɹəm mɛni faɪts, wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm, ən waɪl mɪlət spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə bɹɔd pleɪn ɝaʊn hɪm, hɛvəli mɪkst wɪð stænz ə lɔŋ, θɪn ɡɹæsəz ðət ɹitʃt haɪ ɪn ði ɛɹ. skɹætʃi stɔks ɹʌbd əɡɛns pɛɹɪnz ɑɹmz ɪn ðə wɪnd, meɪkɪŋ ɪm ɪtʃ. ðə ɡɹæsəz smɛl tu dʒɹaɪ, laɪk kʌt heɪ lɛft ɪn ə bɑɹn oʊvɝ ðə wɪntɝ.

He took a deep breath, then closed his eyes and imagined himself jumping. Air rushed around him in a sudden burst, but then his feet hit soft ground. He opened his eyes. A large gray wolf, scarred from many fights, was sitting on the ground beside him, and wild millet spread out in a broad plain around him, heavily mixed with stands of long, thin grasses that reached high in the air. Scratchy stalks rubbed against Perrin's arms in the wind, making him itch. The grasses smelled too dry, like cut hay left in a barn over the winter.

səm θɪŋz wɝ tʃɹænzətɔɹi hɪɹ ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim; livz leɪ ɪn ə paɪl baɪ hɪz fiɾ ət wʌn moʊmənt, bʌt ðən wɝ ɡɔn ðə nɛkst. ɛvɹiθɪŋ smɛl dʒʌs feɪnli steɪl, əz ɪf ɪt wɝn kwaɪt ðɛɹ.

Some things were transitory here in the Wolf Dream; leaves lay in a pile by his feet at one moment, but then were gone the next. Everything smelled just faintly stale, as if it weren't quite there.

hi lʊkt ʌp. ðə skaɪ wɑz stɔɹmi. nɔɹməli, klaʊdz ɪn ðɪs pleɪs wɝ əz tʃɹænzətɔɹi əz ʌðɝ θɪŋz. ɪt kəd bi kəmplitli oʊvɝkæst; ðɛn, ɪn ə blɪŋk, ɪt wəd sʌɾənli bi klɪɹ. ðɪs taɪm, ðoʊz dɑɹk stɔɹm klaʊdz ɹɪmeɪnd. ðeɪ bɔɪld, spʌn, ən ʃɑt laɪnz ə laɪtnɪŋ bɪtwin dɪfɹən θʌndɝhɛdz. jɛt ðə laɪtnɪŋ nɛvɝ stʃɹʌk ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ɪt meɪd noʊ nɔɪz.

He looked up. The sky was stormy. Normally, clouds in this place were as transitory as other things. It could be completely overcast; then, in a blink, it would suddenly be clear. This time, those dark storm clouds remained. They boiled, spun, and shot lines of lightning between different thunderheads. Yet the lightning never struck the ground, and it made no noise.

ðə pleɪn wɑz ɑdli saɪlənt. ðə klaʊdz ʃɹaʊɾɪd ði ɪntaɪɝ skaɪ, ɑmənəs. ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt liv.

The plain was oddly silent. The clouds shrouded the entire sky, ominous. And they did not leave.

ðə læs hʌn kʌmz. hɑpɝ lʊkt ʌp ət ðə skaɪ. wɪl ɹʌn təɡɛðɝ, ðɛn. ənlɛs wi slip ɪnstɛd.

The Last Hunt comes. Hopper looked up at the sky. We will run together, then. Unless we sleep instead.

"slip?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wʌɾ ə ðə læs hʌnt?"

"Sleep?" Perrin said. "What of the Last Hunt?"

ɪt kʌmz, hɑpɝ əɡɹid. ɪf ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ fɔlz tə ðə stɔɹm, ɔl wɪl slip fɝɛvɝ. ɪf i laɪvz, ðən wɪl hʌn təɡɛðɝ. jə ən ʌs.

It comes, Hopper agreed. If Shadowkiller falls to the storm, all will sleep forever. If he lives, then we will hunt together. You and us.

pɛɹɪn ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɔɹt θɹu ðə sɛndɪŋ ʌv ɪmədʒəz, smɛlz, saʊnz, filɪŋz. ɪt meɪd lɪɾəl sɛns tə hɪm.

Perrin rubbed his chin, trying to sort through the Sending of images, smells, sounds, feelings. It made little sense to him.

bʌt, wɛl, hi wɑz hɪɹ naʊ. hid wɑntəd tə kʌm, ən hid dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət hid ɡɛt səm ænsɝz fɹəm hɑpɝ, ɪf i kʊd. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə si hɑpɝ əɡɛn.

But, well, he was here now. He'd wanted to come, and he'd decided that he'd get some answers from Hopper, if he could. It was good to see Hopper again.

ɹʌn, hɑpɝ sɛnt. hɪz sɛndɪŋ wɑz nɑɾ əlɑɹmd. ɪt wɑz ən ɔfɝ. lɛɾ əs ɹʌn təɡɛðɝ.

Run, Hopper sent. His Sending was not alarmed. It was an offer. Let us run together.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, ən bɪɡæn tə dʒɑɡ θɹu ðə ɡɹæsəz. hɑpɝ loʊp bɪsaɪd hɪm, sɛndɪŋ əmjuzmənt. tu lɛɡz, jʌŋ bʊl? tu lɛɡz ɑɹ sloʊ! ðət sɛndɪŋ wɑz ən ɪmədʒ ə mɛn stʌmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛmsɛlvz, tʃɹɪpɪŋ kəz ə ðɛɹ ɪlɔŋɡeɪɾəd, sɪli lɛɡz.

Perrin nodded, and began to jog through the grasses. Hopper loped beside him, sending amusement. Two legs, Young Bull? Two legs are slow! That Sending was an image of men stumbling over themselves, tripping because of their elongated, silly legs.

pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ hæv tə kip kəntʃɹoʊl, hɑpɝ," hi sɛd. "wɛn aɪ lɛt ðə wʊlf teɪk kəntʃɹoʊl . . .

Perrin hesitated. "I have to keep control, Hopper," he said. "When I let the wolf take control . . .

wɛl, aɪ də deɪnʒɝəs θɪŋz."

well, I do dangerous things."

ðə wʊlf kɑkt ɪz hɛd, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹæsi fild. ðə stɔks kɹʌntʃt ən skɹeɪpt əz ðə tu ʌv əm pæs θɹu, faɪndɪŋ ə smɔl ɡeɪm tʃɹeɪl, tɝnɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪt.

The wolf cocked his head, trotting beside Perrin across the grassy field. The stalks crunched and scraped as the two of them passed through, finding a small game trail, turning along it.

ɹʌn, hɑpɝ ɝdʒd, ɑbviəsli kənfjuzd ət pɛɹɪnz ɹɪlʌktəns.

Run, Hopper urged, obviously confused at Perrin's reluctance.

"aɪ kænt," pɛɹɪn sɛd, stɑpɪŋ. hɑpɝ tɝn ən tʊk ə fju baʊnz bæk tə hɪm. hi smɛl kənfjuzd.

"I can't," Perrin said, stopping. Hopper turned and took a few bounds back to him. He smelled confused.

"hɑpɝ, aɪ fɹaɪɾən maɪsɛlf," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "wɛn aɪ luz kəntʃɹoʊl. ðə fɝs taɪm ɪt hæpən tə mi wɑz dʒʌst æftɝ aɪ mɛt ðə wʊlvz. jə nid tə hɛlp mi ʌndɝstænd."

"Hopper, I frighten myself," Perrin said, "when I lose control. The first time it happened to me was just after I met the wolves. You need to help me understand."

hɑpɝ sɪmpli kəntɪnjud tə stɛɹ ət hɪm, tʌŋ hæŋɪŋ aʊt ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz maʊθ dʒʌst slaɪtli, dʒɔz pɑɹɾəd.

Hopper simply continued to stare at him, tongue hanging out the front of his mouth just slightly, jaws parted.

waɪ æm aɪ duɪŋ ðɪs? pɛɹɪn θɔt, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. wʊlvz dɪdn θɪŋk laɪk mɛn. wʌɾ ɪt mæɾɝ wʌt hɑpɝ θɔɾ ʌv ɪɾ ɔl?

Why am I doing this? Perrin thought, shaking his head. Wolves didn't think like men. What did it matter what Hopper thought of it all?

wɪl hʌn təɡɛðɝ, hɑpɝ sɛnt.

We will hunt together, Hopper sent.

"wʌɾ ɪf aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hʌnt wɪð ju?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. seɪɪŋ ðə wɝdz meɪɾ ɪz hɑɹt twɪst. hi dɪd laɪk ðɪs pleɪs, ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, deɪnʒɝəs ðoʊ ɪt kəd bi. ðəɹ wɝ wʌndɝfəl θɪŋz əbaʊt wʌt hæd hæpən tə hɪm sɪns livɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

"What if I don't want to hunt with you?" Perrin said. Saying the words made his heart twist. He did like this place, the wolf dream, dangerous though it could be. There were wonderful things about what had happened to him since leaving the Two Rivers.

bʌɾ i kʊdn kəntɪnju tə luz kəntʃɹoʊl. hi hæd tə faɪn ə bæləns. θɹoʊɪŋ əweɪ ði æks hæd meɪɾ ə dɪfɝəns. ði æks ən ðə hæmɝ wɝ dɪfɹənt wɛpənz - wʌn kəd bi juzd oʊnli fəɹ kɪlɪŋ, waɪl ði ʌðɝ ɡeɪv ɪm ə tʃɔɪs.

But he couldn't continue to lose control. He had to find a balance. Throwing away the axe had made a difference. The axe and the hammer were different weapons - one could be used only for killing, while the other gave him a choice.

bʌɾ i hæd tə meɪk ɡʊɾ ɑn ðət tʃɔɪs. hi hæd tə kəntʃɹoʊl hɪmsɛlf. ən ðə fɝst stɛp sim tə bi lɝnɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə wʊlf wɪðɪn hɪm.

But he had to make good on that choice. He had to control himself. And the first step seemed to be learning to control the wolf within him.

ɹʌn wɪð mi, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛnt. fɝɡɛt ðiz θɔts. ɹʌn laɪk ə wʊlf.

Run with me, Young Bull, Hopper sent. Forget these thoughts. Run like a wolf.

"aɪ kænt," pɛɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. hi tɝnd, skænɪŋ ðə pleɪnz. "bʌɾ aɪ nid tə noʊ ðɪs pleɪs, hɑpɝ. aɪ nid tə lɝn haʊ tə juz ɪt, kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt."

"I can't," Perrin replied. He turned, scanning the plains. "But I need to know this place, Hopper. I need to learn how to use it, control it."

mɛn, hɑpɝ θɔt, sɛndɪŋ ðə smɛlz ə dɪsmɪsɪvnəs ən æŋɡɝ. kəntʃɹoʊl. ɔlweɪz kəntʃɹoʊl.

Men, Hopper thought, Sending the smells of dismissiveness and anger. Control. Always control.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə titʃ mi," pɛɹɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ðə wʊlf. "aɪ wɑnə mæstɝ ðɪs pleɪs. wɪl jə ʃoʊ mi haʊ?"

"I want you to teach me," Perrin said, turning back to the wolf. "I want to master this place. Will you show me how?"

hɑpɝ sæt bæk ɑn ɪz hɔntʃɪz.

Hopper sat back on his haunches.

"faɪn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ wɪl sɝtʃ aʊɾ ʌðɝ wʊlvz u wɪl."

"Fine," Perrin said. "I will search out other wolves who will."

hi tɝnd, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ daʊn ðə ɡeɪm tʃɹeɪl. hi dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɪs pleɪs, bʌt hid lɝn ðət ðə wʊlf dʒɹim wɑz ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl. ðɪs mɛdoʊ wɪð ðə weɪst-haɪ ɡɹæs ən ɪts stænz ə ju kəd bi ɛniwɛɹ. wɛɹ wəɾ i faɪnd wʊlvz? hi kwɛstəɾ aʊt wɪð ɪz maɪnd, ən faʊn ðəɾ ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ dɪfəkəl tə də hɪɹ.

He turned, striking down the game trail. He didn't recognize this place, but he'd learned that the wolf dream was unpredictable. This meadow with the waist-high grass and its stands of yew could be anywhere. Where would he find wolves? He quested out with his mind, and found that it was much more difficult to do here.

jə doʊnt wɑnə ɹʌn. bʌt jə lʊk fəɹ wʊlvz. waɪ ɑɹ jə soʊ dɪfəkəlt, kʌb? hɑpɝ sæɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ɪn ðə ɡɹæs.

You don't want to run. But you look for wolves. Why are you so difficult, cub? Hopper sat in front of him in the grass.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌmbəld, ðən tʊk ə lip ðət lɔntʃt ɪm θɹu ði ɛɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɑɹdz. hi lændəd wɪð ɪz fʊt fɔlɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹæs əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn ə nɔɹməl stɛp.

Perrin grumbled, then took a leap that launched him through the air a hundred yards. He landed with his foot falling to the grass as if it had been a normal step.

ən ðəɹ hɑpɝ wɑz əhɛɾ ə hɪm. pɛɹɪn hædn sin ðə wʊlf lip. hi hæd bɪn ɪn wʌn pleɪs, ən naʊ ɪn ənʌðɝ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, kwɛstɪŋ aʊɾ əɡɛn. fəɹ ʌðɝ wʊlvz. hi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ, dɪstənt. hi niɾəd tə pʊʃ hɑɹɾɝ. hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd, dʒɹu mɔɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪndə hɪmsɛlf, sʌmhaʊ, ən mænədʒ tə pʊʃ ɪz maɪn fɑɹðɝ.

And there Hopper was ahead of him. Perrin hadn't seen the wolf leap. He had been in one place, and now in another. Perrin gritted his teeth, questing out again. For other wolves. He felt something, distant. He needed to push harder. He concentrated, drew more strength into himself, somehow, and managed to push his mind farther.

ðɪs ɪz deɪnʒɝəs, jʌŋ bʊl, hɑpɝ sɛnt. jə kʌm hɪɹ tu stʃɹɔŋli. jəl daɪ.

This is dangerous, Young Bull, Hopper sent. You come here too strongly. You will die.

"ju ɔlweɪz seɪ ðæt," pɛɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "tɛl mi wʌɾ aɪ wɑnə noʊ. ʃoʊ mi haʊ tə lɝn."

"You always say that," Perrin replied. "Tell me what I want to know. Show me how to learn."

stʌbɝn pʌp, hɑpɝ sɛnt. ɹɪtɝn wən jə ɑɹən dɪtɝmən tə poʊk jəɹ snaʊɾ ɪndə ə faɪɹisps dɛn.

Stubborn pup, Hopper Sent. Return when you aren't determined to poke your snout into a fireasp's den.

wɪð ðæt, sʌmθɪŋ slæmd əɡɛns pɛɹɪn, ə weɪɾ əɡɛnst ɪz maɪnd. ɛvɹiθɪŋ vænɪʃt, ən i wɑz tɔst - laɪk ə lif bɪfɔɹ ə stɔɹm - aʊɾ ə ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

With that, something slammed against Perrin, a weight against his mind. Everything vanished, and he was tossed - like a leaf before a storm - out of the wolf dream.

feɪl fɛlt əɹ hʌzbən stɝ nɛks tə hɝ əz i slɛpt. ʃi ɡlænst əɾ ɪm ɪn ðə dɑɹk tɛnt; ðoʊ ʃi leɪ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɑn ðə pælət, ʃi hædn bɪn slipɪŋ. ʃid bɪn weɪɾɪŋ, lɪsnɪŋ tə hɪz bɹɛθs. hi tɝn ɑntu hɪz bæk, mʌɾɝɪŋ dʒɹaʊsəli.

Faile felt her husband stir next to her as he slept. She glanced at him in the dark tent; though she lay beside him on the pallet, she hadn't been sleeping. She'd been waiting, listening to his breaths. He turned onto his back, muttering drowsily.

ʌv ɔl ðə naɪts fəɹ ɪm tə bi ɹɛsləs . . . ʃi θɔt wɪð ənɔɪəns.

Of all the nights for him to be restless . . . she thought with annoyance.

ðeɪ wɝ ə wik aʊɾ ə mɔldən. ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz hæd meɪd kæmp - ɔɹ, wɛl, kæmps - nɪɹ ə wɔɾɝweɪ ðət lɛd stʃɹeɪt tə ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd, wɪtʃ wɑz oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ.

They were a week out of Malden. The refugees had made camp - or, well, camps - near a waterway that led straight to the Jehannah Road, which was only a short distance away.

θɪŋz hæd ɡɔn smuðli ðiz læs fju deɪz, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn hæd dʒʌdʒ ði æʃəmən tu taɪɝd stɪl tə meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz. ʃi hæd spɛn ði ivnɪŋ wɪð əɹ hʌzbənd, ɹimaɪndɪŋ ɪm ə sɛvɹəl ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɹizənz waɪ hid mɛɹiɾ əɹ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. hid sɝɾənli bɪn ɪnθuziæstɪk, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz ðəɾ ɑɾ ɛdʒ tə hɪz aɪz. nɑɾ ə deɪnʒɝəs ɛdʒ, dʒʌst ə sɑɹoʊfəl wʌn. hi hæd ɡɹoʊn hɔntəd waɪl ðeɪ wɝ əpɑɹt. ʃi kəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt. ʃi hæɾ ə fju ɡoʊsts ə hɝ oʊn. wʌn kəd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛvɹiθɪŋ tə ɹɪmeɪn ðə seɪm, ən ʃi kəd tɛl ðəɾ i stɪl lʌvd əɹ - lʌvd əɹ fɪɹsli. ðət wɑz ɪnʌf, ən soʊ ʃi dɪdnt wɝi ɑn ɪt fɝðɝ.

Things had gone smoothly these last few days, though Perrin had judged the Asha'man too tired still to make gateways. She had spent the evening with her husband, reminding him of several important reasons why he'd married her in the first place. He'd certainly been enthusiastic, though there was that odd edge to his eyes. Not a dangerous edge, just a sorrowful one. He had grown haunted while they were apart. She could understand that. She had a few ghosts of her own. One could not expect everything to remain the same, and she could tell that he still loved her - loved her fiercely. That was enough, and so she didn't worry on it further.

bʌt ʃi wɑz plænɪŋ ən ɑɹɡjəmən ðət wəd pʊl ɪz sikɹəts fɹəm hɪm. ʃi wəd weɪɾ ə fju mɔɹ deɪz fəɹ ðæt. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə ɹimaɪn ə hʌzbən ðət wʌn wəd nɑt sɪt kɑntɛnt wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ i dɪd, bʌɾ ɪt wʊdn də tə meɪk ɪm θɪŋk ʃi wɑz ʌnəpɹiʃieɪɾɪv tə hæv ɪm bæk.

But she was planning an argument that would pull his secrets from him. She would wait a few more days for that. It was good to remind a husband that one would not sit content with everything he did, but it wouldn't do to make him think she was unappreciative to have him back.

kwaɪt ði ɑpəzət. ʃi smaɪld, ɹoʊlɪŋ oʊvɝ ən leɪɪŋ əɹ hæn ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, fɝd wɪð hɛɹ, hɝ hɛɾ ɑn ɪz bɛɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi lʌv ðɪs bɝli, tʌmbəlɪŋ ævəlæntʃ ʌv ə mæn. biɪŋ bæk wɪð ɪm wɑz swiɾɝ, ivən, ðən ðə vɪktɝi ʌv əɹ ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ.

Quite the opposite. She smiled, rolling over and laying her hand on his chest, furred with hair, her head on his bare shoulder. She loved this burly, tumbling avalanche of a man. Being back with him was sweeter, even, than the victory of her escape from the Shaido.

hɪz aɪz flʌɾɝd oʊpən ən ʃi saɪd. lʌv ɪm əɹ nɑt, ʃi wɪʃt hid ɹɪmeɪn əslip ðɪs naɪt!

His eyes fluttered open and she sighed. Love him or not, she wished he'd remain asleep this night!

hædnt ʃi taɪɝɾ ɪm aʊɾ ɪnʌf?

Hadn't she tired him out enough?

hi lʊkt ət hɝ; hɪz ɡoʊldən aɪz sim tə ɡloʊ dʒʌs feɪnli ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ðoʊ ʃi nu ɪt wɑz ə tʃɹɪk ə ðə laɪt. ðən i pʊld əɹ ə lɪɾəl kloʊsɝ. "aɪ dɪdn slip wɪð bɹəleɪn," hi sɛd, vɔɪs ɡɹʌf. "noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə ɹumɝz seɪ."

He looked at her; his golden eyes seemed to glow just faintly in the darkness, though she knew it was a trick of the light. Then he pulled her a little closer. "I didn't sleep with Berelain," he said, voice gruff. "No matter what the rumors say."

dɪɹ, swit, blʌn pɛɹɪn. "aɪ noʊ jə dɪdnt," ʃi sɛd kənsoʊlɪŋli. ʃid hɝd ðə ɹumɝz.

Dear, sweet, blunt Perrin. "I know you didn't," she said consolingly. She'd heard the rumors.

vɝtʃuəli ɛvɹi wʊmən ʃid tɔk tə ɪn ðə kæmp, fɹəm ɛɛs sədaɪ tə sɝvənt, hæd pɹitɛndəd ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld əɹ tʌŋ, jɛt spɪl ðə seɪm nuz. pɛɹɪn, spɛndɪŋ ə naɪɾ ɪn ðə fɝst ə minz tɛnt.

Virtually every woman she'd talked to in the camp, from Aes Sedai to servant, had pretended she was trying to hold her tongue, yet spilled the same news. Perrin, spending a night in the First of Mayene's tent.

"noʊ, ɹɪli," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ə pliɾɪŋ toʊn ɛntɝɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs. "aɪ dɪdnt, feɪl. pliz."

"No, really," Perrin said, a pleading tone entering his voice. "I didn't, Faile. Please."

"aɪ sɛɾ aɪ bɪliv ju."

"I said I believed you."

"ju saʊndəd . . . aɪ doʊnt noʊ. bɝn ɪt, wʊmən, jə saʊndəd dʒɛləs."

"You sounded . . . I don't know. Burn it, woman, you sounded jealous."

wəɾ i nɛvɝ lɝn? "pɛɹɪn," ʃi sɛd flætli. "ɪt tʊk mi ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ə jɪɹ - nɑt tə mɛnʃən kənsɪɾɝəbəl tʃɹʌbəl - tə sɪdus ju, ən ðən ɪɾ oʊnli wɝkt kəz ðəɹ wɑz ə mɛɹɪdʒ ɪnvɑlvd! bɹəleɪn hæzən ðə skɪl tə hændəl ju."

Would he never learn? "Perrin," she said flatly. "It took me the better part of a year - not to mention considerable trouble - to seduce you, and then it only worked because there was a marriage involved! Berelain hasn't the skill to handle you."

hi ɹitʃt ɪz ɹaɪt hæn ʌp, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz bɪɹd, simɪŋ kənfjuzd. ðən i dʒʌst smaɪld.

He reached his right hand up, scratching his beard, seeming confused. Then he just smiled.

"bɪsaɪdz," ʃi æɾəd, snʌɡəlɪŋ kloʊsɝ, "ju spoʊk ðə wɝdz. ən aɪ tʃɹʌs ju."

"Besides," she added, snuggling closer, "you spoke the words. And I trust you."

"soʊ jəɹ nɑt dʒɛləs?"

"So you're not jealous?"

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪ æm," ʃi sɛd, swɑɾɪŋ ɪz tʃɛst. "pɛɹɪn, hævən aɪ ɪkspleɪn ðɪs? ə hʌzbənd nidz tə noʊ hɪz waɪf ɪz dʒɛləs, ʌðɝwaɪz i woʊn ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi kɛɹz fəɹ hɪm. jə ɡɑɹd ðət wɪtʃ jə faɪn moʊs pɹɛʃəs. ɑnəsli, ɪf jə kip meɪkɪŋ mi spɛl θɪŋz aʊt laɪk ðɪs, ðən aɪ woʊn əv ɛni sikɹəts lɛft!"

"Of course I am," she said, swatting his chest. "Perrin, haven't I explained this? A husband needs to know his wife is jealous, otherwise he won't realize how much she cares for him. You guard that which you find most precious. Honestly, if you keep making me spell things out like this, then I won't have any secrets left!"

hi snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli ət ðət læs kɑmɛnt. "aɪ daʊt ðæts pɑsəbəl."

He snorted softly at that last comment. "I doubt that's possible."

hi ɡɹu kwaɪət, ən ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, hoʊpɪŋ hid ɡoʊ bæk tə slip. aʊtsaɪd ðə tɛnt, ʃi kəd hɪɹ ðə dɪstən vɔɪsəz ʌv ɡɑɹdz tʃæɾɪŋ ɑn pətʃɹoʊl ən ðə saʊn ʌv wʌn ə ðə fɛɹiɝz - dʒɛɝæsɪd, æɛmɪn əɹ fɑltən - wɝkɪŋ leɪɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt, paʊndɪŋ aʊɾ ə ʃu əɹ neɪl tə ɹɛɾi wʌn ə ðə hɔɹsəz fəɹ ðə nɛks deɪz mɑɹtʃ. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə hɪɹ ðət saʊn əɡɛn. ði il wɝ jusləs wən ɪt keɪm tə hɔɹsəz, ən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæɾ iðɝ ɹilis ðə wʌnz ðeɪ kæptʃɝɾ əɹ tɝn əm ɪndə wɝkhɔɹsɪz. ʃi hæd sin mɛni faɪn sæɾəl mɛɹz pʊlɪŋ kɑɹts dʊɹɪŋ əɹ deɪz ɪn mɔldən.

He grew quiet, and she closed her eyes, hoping he'd go back to sleep. Outside the tent, she could hear the distant voices of guards chatting on patrol and the sound of one of the farriers - Jerasid, Aemin or Falton - working late into the night, pounding out a shoe or nail to ready one of the horses for the next day's march. It was good to hear that sound again. The Aiel were useless when it came to horses, and the Shaido had either released the ones they captured or turned them into workhorses. She had seen many fine saddle mares pulling carts during her days in Malden.

ʃəɾ ɪt fil stʃɹeɪnʒ tə bi bæk? ʃi hæd spɛn lɛs ðən tu mʌnθs əz ə kæptɪv, bʌɾ ɪt hæd sim laɪk jɪɹz. jɪɹz spɛn ɹʌnɪŋ ɛɹənz fəɹ sɪvænə, biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli. bʌt ðət taɪm hæd nɑt bɹoʊkən hɝ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃid fɛl mɔɹ laɪk ə noʊbəlwʊmən dʊɹɪŋ ðoʊz deɪz ðən ʃi hæd bɪfɔɹ.

Should it feel strange to be back? She had spent less than two months as a captive, but it had seemed like years. Years spent running errands for Sevanna, being punished arbitrarily. But that time had not broken her. Strangely, she'd felt more like a noblewoman during those days than she had before.

ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ʃi hædn kwaɪɾ ʌndɝstʊd wʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə bi ə leɪɾi əntɪl mɔldən. oʊ, ʃid hæɾ əɹ ʃɛɹ ə vɪktɝiz. tʃɑ feɪl, ðə pipəl ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, æliændɝ ən pɛɹɪnz kæmp mɛmbɝz.

It was as if she hadn't quite understood what it was to be a lady until Malden. Oh, she'd had her share of victories. Cha Faile, the people of the Two Rivers, Alliandre and Perrin's camp members.

ʃid pʊɾ əɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə juz, hɛlpɪŋ pɛɹɪn lɝn tə bi ə liɾɝ. ɔl ə ðɪs hæd bɪn ɪmpɔɹɾənt, hæd ɹikwaɪɝɾ əɹ tə juz wʌɾ əɹ mʌðɝ ən fɑðɝ hæd tʃɹeɪn əɹ tə bi.

She'd put her training to use, helping Perrin learn to be a leader. All of this had been important, had required her to use what her mother and father had trained her to be.

bʌt mɔldən hæɾ oʊpən əɹ aɪz. ðɛɹ, ʃi hæd faʊn pipəl u hæd niɾəd əɹ mɔɹ ðən ʃiɾ ɛvɝ bɪn niɾəd bɪfɔɹ. bɪniθ sɪvænəz kɹuəl dɪkteɪɾɝʃɪp, ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɡeɪmz, noʊ ɹum fəɹ mɪsteɪks. ʃi hæd bɪn hjumɪlieɪɾɪd, biɾən ən nɪɹli kɪld. ən ðət hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ə tʃɹu ʌndɝstændɪŋ ʌv wʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə bi ə lidʒ leɪɾi. ʃi æktʃəli  fɛlt ə stæb ʌv ɡɪl fəɹ ðə taɪmz ʃi hæd lɔɹɾɪd oʊvɝ pɛɹɪn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs ɪm - əɹ ʌðɝz - tə bɛn tə hɝ wɪl. biɪŋ ə noʊbəlwʊmən mɛnt ɡoʊɪŋ fɝst. ɪt mɛn biɪŋ biɾən soʊ ʌðɝz wɝ nɑt. ɪt mɛn sækɹəfaɪsɪŋ, ɹɪskɪŋ dɛθ, tə pɹətɛk ðoʊz u dɪpɛndəɾ əpɑn ju.

But Malden had opened her eyes. There, she had found people who had needed her more than she'd ever been needed before. Beneath Sevanna's cruel dictatorship, there had been no time for games, no room for mistakes. She had been humiliated, beaten and nearly killed. And that had given her a true understanding of what it was to be a liege lady. She actually felt a stab of guilt for the times she had lorded over Perrin, trying to force him - or others - to bend to her will. Being a noblewoman meant going first. It meant being beaten so others were not. It meant sacrificing, risking death, to protect those who depended upon you.

noʊ, ɪt dɪdn fil stʃɹeɪnʒ tə bi bæk, fəɹ ʃid teɪkən mɔldən - ðə pɑɹts ðət mæɾɝd - wɪð hɝ.

No, it didn't feel strange to be back, for she'd taken Malden - the parts that mattered - with her.

hʌnʒɹədz hæd swɔɹn əlidʒəns tə hɝ əmʌŋ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn, ən ʃi hæd seɪv ðɛm. ʃi hæd dʌn ɪt θɹu pɛɹɪn, bʌt ʃi hæd meɪd plænz, ən wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ʃi wʊɾə ɪskeɪpt ən bɹɔt bæk ən ɑɹmi tə fɹi ðoʊz u hæd swɔɹn tə hɝ.

Hundreds had sworn allegiance to her among the gai'shain, and she had saved them. She had done it through Perrin, but she had made plans, and one way or another, she would have escaped and brought back an army to free those who had sworn to her.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn kɑsts. bʌt ʃi wəd dil wɪð ðoʊz leɪɾɝ tənaɪt, laɪt wɪlɪŋ. ʃi oʊpən ən aɪ ən pikt ət pɛɹɪn. hi sim tə bi slipɪŋ, bʌt wɑz ɪz bɹɛθ ivən? ʃi slɪpt əɹ ɑɹm fɹi.

There had been costs. But she would deal with those later tonight, Light willing. She opened an eye and peeked at Perrin. He seemed to be sleeping, but was his breath even? She slipped her arm free.

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ wʌt hæpən tə ju," hi sɛd.

"I don't care what happened to you," he said.

ʃi saɪd. noʊ, nɑɾ əslip. "wʌt hæpən tə mi?" ʃi æskt wɪð kənfjuʒən.

She sighed. No, not asleep. "What happened to me?" she asked with confusion.

hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə tɛnt. "ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ðə mæn u wɑz wɪð jə wən aɪ seɪv ju. wʌtɛvɝ i dɪd . . . wʌtɛvɝ jə dɪd tə sɝvaɪv. ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt."

He opened his eyes, staring up at the tent. "The Shaido, the man who was with you when I saved you. Whatever he did . . . whatever you did to survive. It's all right."

wɑz ðət wʌt wɑz bɑðɝɪŋ hɪm? laɪt! "ju bɪɡ ɑks," ʃi sɛd, θʌmpɪŋ ə fɪst ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, kɑzɪŋ ɪm tə ɡɹʌnt. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ? ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi ɔl ɹaɪt fəɹ mi tə bi ənfeɪθfəl? dʒʌst æftɝ jə wɝ soʊ kənsɝn tə tɛl mi ðət jə hædn bɪn?"

Was that what was bothering him? Light! "You big ox," she said, thumping a fist on his chest, causing him to grunt. "What are you saying? That it would be all right for me to be unfaithful? Just after you were so concerned to tell me that you hadn't been?"

"wʌt? noʊ, ɪts dɪfɹənt, feɪl. jə wɝ ə pɹɪznɝ, ən - "

"What? No, it's different, Faile. You were a prisoner, and - "

"æn aɪ kæn kɛɹ fəɹ maɪsɛlf? jə ɑɹ ən ɑks. noʊ wʌn tʌtʃt mi. ðəɹ il. jə noʊ ðeɪ wʊdn dɛɹ hɑɹm ə ɡeɪʃeɪn." ɪt wɑzn kwaɪt tʃɹu; wɪmən hæɾ ɔfən bɪn əbjuzd ɪn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp, fəɹ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd stɑpt æktɪŋ laɪk il.

"And I can't care for myself? You are an ox. No one touched me. They're Aiel. You know they wouldn't dare harm a gai'shain." It wasn't quite true; women had often been abused in the Shaido camp, for the Shaido had stopped acting like Aiel.

bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn ʌðɝz ɪn ðə kæmp, il u hædn bɪn ʃeɪɾoʊ. mɛn u hæd ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɹænd əz ðɛɹ kɑɹəkɑɹn, bʌɾ u ɔlsoʊ hæd tʃɹʌbəl æksɛptɪŋ ʃeɪɾoʊ əθɔɹəɾi. ðə bɹʌðɝləs hæd bɪn mɛn ʌv ɑnɝ; ðoʊ ðeɪd kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz kæst ɔf, ðeɪ hæd bɪn ði oʊnli wʌnz ɪn mɔldən u hæd meɪnteɪn ði oʊld weɪz. wən ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn wɪmən hæd stɑɹɾəd tə bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ, ðə bɹʌðɝləs hæd tʃoʊzən ən pɹətɛktəd ðoʊz ðeɪ kʊd. ðeɪ hædn æskt ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ ɛfɝts.

But there had been others in the camp, Aiel who hadn't been Shaido. Men who had refused to accept Rand as their Car'a'carn, but who also had trouble accepting Shaido authority. The Brotherless had been men of honor; though they'd called themselves cast off, they had been the only ones in Malden who had maintained the old ways. When the gai'shain women had started to be in danger, the Brotherless had chosen and protected those they could. They hadn't asked anything for their efforts.

wɛl . . . ðət wɑzn tʃɹu. ðeɪ hæɾ æsk fəɹ mʌtʃ, bʌt hæd dɪmændəd nʌθɪŋ. ɹoʊlən hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ən il tə hɝ ɪn ækʃən, ɪf nɑɾ ɪn wɝd. bʌt, laɪk mæsiməz dɛθ, hɝ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp wɪð ɹoʊlən wɑz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ pɛɹɪn niɾəd tə noʊ əbaʊt. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz kɪst ɹoʊlən, bʌt ʃi hæd juzd ɪz dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ əɹ əz ən ædvæntɪdʒ. ən ʃi səspɛktəd ðət hid noʊn wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ.

Well . . . that wasn't true. They had asked for much, but had demanded nothing. Rolan had always been an Aiel to her in action, if not in word. But, like Masema's death, her relationship with Rolan was not something Perrin needed to know about. She had never so much as kissed Rolan, but she had used his desire for her as an advantage. And she suspected that he'd known what she was doing.
