pɛɹɪn hæd kɪld ɹoʊlən. ðət wɑz ənʌðɝ ɹizən ðəɾ əɹ hʌzbən dɪdnt nid tə noʊ əbaʊt ðə bɹʌðɝləs mænz kaɪndnəs. ɪt wəd tɛɹ pɛɹɪn əpɑɹɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪf i nu wʌt hid dʌn.

Perrin had killed Rolan. That was another reason that her husband didn't need to know about the Brotherless man's kindness. It would tear Perrin apart inside if he knew what he'd done.

pɛɹɪn ɹɪlækst, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz. hi hæd tʃeɪnʒd dʊɹɪŋ ðiz tu mʌnθs, pɝhæps əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi hæd. ðət wɑz ɡʊd. ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, hɝ pipəl hæɾ ə seɪɪŋ: "oʊnli ðə dɑɹk wʌn steɪz ðə seɪm." mɛn ɡɹu ən pɹəɡɹɛst; ðə ʃædoʊ dʒʌst ɹɪmeɪn əz ɪt wɑz. ivəl.

Perrin relaxed, closing his eyes. He had changed during these two months, perhaps as much as she had. That was good. In the Borderlands, her people had a saying: "Only the Dark One stays the same." Men grew and progressed; the Shadow just remained as it was. Evil.

"wil əv tə də səm plænɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, jɔnɪŋ. "wʌns ɡeɪtweɪz ɑɹ əveɪləbəl, wɪl əv tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə fɔɹs ðə pipəl tə liv, ən dɪsaɪɾ u ɡoʊz fɝst.

"We'll have to do some planning tomorrow," Perrin said, yawning. "Once gateways are available, we will have to decide whether to force the people to leave, and decide who goes first.

hæz ɛniwʌn dɪskʌvɝd wʌt hæpən tə mæsimə?"

Has anyone discovered what happened to Masema?"

"nɑt ðəɾ aɪ noʊ ʌv," ʃi sɛd kɛɹfəli. "bʌt wɪð soʊ mɛni ʌv ɪz pəzɛʃənz ɡɔn fɹəm ɪz tɛnt. . . ."

"Not that I know of," she said carefully. "But with so many of his possessions gone from his tent. . . ."

"mæsimə dʌzn kɛɹ əbaʊt pəzɛʃənz," pɛɹɪn mʌmbəl kwaɪətli, aɪz stɪl kloʊzd. "ðoʊ meɪbi hi wʊɾə teɪkən əm tə ɹibɪld. aɪ ɡɛs i maɪɾ əv ɹʌn ɔf, ðoʊ ɪts stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət noʊbɑdi noʊz wɛɹ əɹ haʊ."

"Masema doesn't care about possessions," Perrin mumbled quietly, eyes still closed. "Though maybe he would have taken them to rebuild. I guess he might have run off, though it's strange that nobody knows where or how."

"hi pɹɑbli slɪpt əweɪ dʊɹɪŋ ðə kənfjuʒən æftɝ ðə bæɾəl."

"He probably slipped away during the confusion after the battle."

"pɹɑbli," pɛɹɪn əɡɹid. "aɪ wʌndɝ . . ." hi jɔnd. "aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt ɹænd wɪl seɪ. mæsimə wɑz ðə pɔɪn ə ðɪs hoʊl tʃɹɪp. aɪ wɑz tə fɛtʃ ɪm ən bɹɪŋ ɪm bæk, ən aɪ ɡɛs aɪv feɪld."

"Probably," Perrin agreed. "I wonder . . ." He yawned. "I wonder what Rand will say. Masema was the point of this whole trip. I was to fetch him and bring him back, and I guess I've failed."

"ju dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə mɛn u wɝ mɝɾɝɪŋ ən ɹɑbɪŋ ɪn ðə dʒɹæɡənz neɪm," feɪl sɛd, "æn jə kʌɾ aʊt ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ liɾɝʃɪp, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ɔl juv lɝn əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn. aɪ θɪŋk ðə dʒɹæɡən wɪl faɪn ðət wʌt juv əkɑmplɪʃt hɪɹ fɑɹ aʊtweɪz nɑt bɹɪŋɪŋ mæsimə bæk."

"You destroyed the men who were murdering and robbing in the Dragon's name," Faile said, "and you cut out the heart of the Shaido leadership, not to mention all you've learned about the Seanchan. I think the Dragon will find that what you've accomplished here far outweighs not bringing Masema back."

"meɪbi jəɹ ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn mʌmbəl slipəli. "blæstəd kʌlɝz. . . . aɪ doʊnt wɑnə wɑtʃ jə slipɪŋ, ɹænd. wʌt hæpən tə jəɹ hænd? laɪt-blaɪndɪd ful, teɪk bɛɾɝ kɛɹ ə jɝsɛlf. . . .

"Maybe you're right," Perrin mumbled sleepily. "Blasted colors. . . . I don't want to watch you sleeping, Rand. What happened to your hand? Light-blinded fool, take better care of yourself. . . .

jəɹ ɔl wi hæv. . . . læs hʌn kʌmɪŋ. . . ."

You're all we have. . . . Last Hunt coming. . . ."

ʃi kəd bɛɹli meɪk aʊt ðət læs pɑɹt. waɪ wɑz i tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ɹændz hænd ɡoʊɪŋ hʌntɪŋ?

She could barely make out that last part. Why was he talking about Rand's hand going hunting?

wɑz i æktʃəli  fɔlɪŋ əslip ðɪs taɪm?

Was he actually falling asleep this time?

ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, hi sun stɑɹɾəd snɔɹɪŋ sɔfli. ʃi smaɪld, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd fɑnli. hi wɑz ən ɑks, səmtaɪmz. bʌɾ i wɑz əɹ ɑks. ʃi klaɪmd ɔf ə ðə pæləɾ ən muv θɹu ðɛɹ tɛnt, pʊlɪŋ ɑn ə ɹoʊb ən taɪɪŋ ɪts bɛlt. ə pɛɹ ə sændəlz fɑloʊd, ən ðən ʃi slɪpt aʊt θɹu ðə tɛn flæps.

Sure enough, he soon started snoring softly. She smiled, shaking her head fondly. He was an ox, sometimes. But he was her ox. She climbed off of the pallet and moved through their tent, pulling on a robe and tying its belt. A pair of sandals followed, and then she slipped out through the tent flaps.

ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl ɡɑɹɾəd ðɛɹ, əlɔŋ wɪð tu meɪɾənz. ðə meɪɾənz nɑɾəd tə hɝ; ðeɪ wəd kip əɹ sikɹət.

Arrela and Lacile guarded there, along with two Maidens. The Maidens nodded to her; they would keep her secret.

feɪl lɛf ðə meɪɾən ɡɑɹdz, bʌt tʊk ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl wɪð əɹ əz ʃi wɔkt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. ɹɛlə wɑz ə dɑɹk-hɛɹd tɛɹən wʊmən u wɑz tɔlɝ ðən moʊs meɪɾənz, wɪð ə bɹʌsk weɪ əbaʊt hɝ. lətʃəl wɑz ʃɔɹt, peɪl, ən vɛɹi slɛndɝ, ən ʃi wɔkt wɪð ə ɡɹeɪsfəl sweɪ. ðeɪ wɝ əz dɪfɹən əz wɪmən kəd ɡɛt, pɝhæps, ðoʊ ðɛɹ kæptɪvəɾi hæd junaɪɾəd əm ɔl. boʊθ mɛmbɝz ə tʃɑ feɪl hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd wɪð əɹ ən ɡɔn tə mɔldən əz ɡeɪʃeɪn.

Faile left the Maiden guards, but took Arrela and Lacile with her as she walked out into the darkness. Arrela was a dark-haired Tairen woman who was taller than most Maidens, with a brusque way about her. Lacile was short, pale, and very slender, and she walked with a graceful sway. They were as different as women could get, perhaps, though their captivity had united them all. Both members of Cha Faile had been captured with her and gone to Malden as gai'shain.

æftɝ tʃɹævlɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns, ðeɪ pɪkt ʌp tu ʌðɝ meɪɾənz - beɪn ən kiæd hæd spoʊkən wɪð ðɛm, laɪkli. ðeɪ pæst aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp, muvɪŋ tə ə spɑt wɛɹ ə pɛɹ ʌv wɪloʊ tʃɹiz stʊd saɪd baɪ saɪd. ðɛɹ, feɪl wɑz mɛt baɪ ə pɛɹ ʌv wɪmən u stɪl wɔɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn waɪt. beɪn ən kiæd wɝ meɪɾənz ðɛmsɛlvz, fɝst-sɪstɝz ən dɪɹ tə feɪl. ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ lɔɪəl - ivən - ðən ðoʊz u hæd swɔɹn tə hɝ. lɔɪəl tə hɝ, jɛt fɹi ʌv oʊðz tə hɝ. ə kɑntʃɹədɪkʃən oʊnli il kəd pʊl ɔf.

After traveling a short distance, they picked up two other Maidens - Bain and Chiad had spoken with them, likely. They passed out of the camp, moving to a spot where a pair of willow trees stood side by side. There, Faile was met by a pair of women who still wore gai'shain white. Bain and Chiad were Maidens themselves, first-sisters and dear to Faile. They were more loyal - even - than those who had sworn to her. Loyal to her, yet free of oaths to her. A contradiction only Aiel could pull off.

ənlaɪk feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz, beɪn ən kiæd wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɔf ðə waɪt dʒʌs kəz ðɛɹ kæptɝz hæd bɪn dɪfiɾəd. ðeɪ wəd wɛɹ ðə kloʊðɪŋ fəɹ ə jɪɹ ən ə deɪ. ɪn fækt, kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ ðɪs naɪt  - æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ðɛɹ laɪvz fɹəm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn teɪkən - stʃɹɛtʃt wʌt ðɛɹ ɑnɝ wəɾ əlaʊ. haʊɛvɝ, ðeɪ ədmɪɾəd ðət biɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp hæd bɪn ɛniθɪŋ bʌt stændɝd.

Unlike Faile and the others, Bain and Chiad would not put off the white just because their captors had been defeated. They would wear the clothing for a year and a day. In fact, coming here this night  - acknowledging their lives from before they had been taken - stretched what their honor would allow. However, they admitted that being gai'shain in the Shaido camp had been anything but standard.

feɪl mɛɾ əm wɪð ə smaɪl, bʌt dɪd nɑt ʃeɪm əm baɪ kɔlɪŋ əm baɪ neɪm əɹ baɪ juzɪŋ meɪɾən hæntɔk. haʊɛvɝ, ʃi kʊdn kip hɝsɛlf fɹəm æskɪŋ, "ju ɑɹ wɛl?" əz ʃi æksɛptɪɾ ə smɔl bʌndəl fɹəm kiæd.

Faile met them with a smile, but did not shame them by calling them by name or by using Maiden handtalk. However, she couldn't keep herself from asking, "You are well?" as she accepted a small bundle from Chiad.

kiæd wɑz ə bjuɾəfəl wʊmən wɪð ɡɹeɪ aɪz ən ʃɔɹt, ɹɛɾɪʃ blɑn hɛɹ hɪɾən bɪniθ ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊb. ʃi ɡɹɪməst ət ðə kwɛstʃən. "ɡɔl sɝtʃt ði ɪntaɪɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp tə faɪn mi, ən ɹɪpɔɹts seɪ hi dɪfiɾəd twɛlv ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ wɪð ɪz spɪɹ. pɝhæps aɪ ʃæl əv tə meɪk ə bɹaɪɾəl ɹiθ fəɹ ɪm æftɝ ɔl, wʌns ðɪs ɪz ɔl θɹu."

Chiad was a beautiful woman with gray eyes and short, reddish blond hair hidden beneath the hood of her gai'shain robe. She grimaced at the question. "Gaul searched the entire Shaido camp to find me, and reports say he defeated twelve algai'd'siswai with his spear. Perhaps I shall have to make a bridal wreath for him after all, once this is all through."

feɪl smaɪld.

Faile smiled.

kiæd smaɪl bæk. "hi dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk ðət wʌn ə ðə mɛn i kɪld wəd tɝn aʊt tə bi ðə wʌn tə hum beɪn wɑz ɡeɪʃeɪn. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ɡɔl ɪz hæpi tə hæv boʊθ ʌv əs sɝvɪŋ hɪm."

Chiad smiled back. "He did not expect that one of the men he killed would turn out to be the one to whom Bain was gai'shain. I do not think Gaul is happy to have both of us serving him."

"fulɪʃ mæn," beɪn - ðə tɔlɝ ə ðə tu - sɛd. "vɛɹi laɪk ɪm tə nɑt wɑtʃ wɛɹ i dʒæbd ɪz spɪɹ. hi kʊdn kɪl ðə ɹaɪt mæn wɪθaʊɾ æksədɛntəli sleɪɪŋ ə fju ʌðɝz." boʊθ wɪmən tʃʌkəld.

"Foolish man," Bain - the taller of the two - said. "Very like him to not watch where he jabbed his spear. He couldn't kill the right man without accidentally slaying a few others." Both women chuckled.

feɪl smaɪld ən nɑɾəd; il hjumɝ wɑz bɪɑn hɝ. "θæŋk jə vɛɹi mʌtʃ fəɹ fɛtʃɪŋ ðiz,"

Faile smiled and nodded; Aiel humor was beyond her. "Thank you very much for fetching these,"

ʃi sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ðə smɔl, klɔθ-ɹæp bʌndəl.

she said, holding up the small, cloth-wrapped bundle.

"ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ," kiæd sɛd. "ðɛɹ wɝ tu mɛni hænz wɝkɪŋ ðət deɪ, soʊ ɪt wɑz izi.

"It was nothing," Chiad said. "There were too many hands working that day, so it was easy.

æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn ɔlɹɛɾi weɪts fəɹ jə ət ðə tʃɹiz. wi ʃəd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə kæmp."

Alliandre Maritha Kigarin already waits for you at the trees. We should return to the camp."

"jɛs," beɪn æɾəd. "pɝhæps ɡɔl wəd laɪk ɪz bæk ɹʌbd əɡɛn, əɹ wɔɾɝ fɛtʃt fəɹ hɪm.

"Yes," Bain added. "Perhaps Gaul would like his back rubbed again, or water fetched for him.

hi ɡɹoʊz soʊ æŋɡɹi wən wi æsk, bʌt ɡeɪʃeɪn ɡeɪn ɑnɝ oʊnli θɹu sɝvəs. wʌɾ ɛls ɑɹ wi tə du?"

He grows so angry when we ask, but gai'shain gain honor only through service. What else are we to do?"

ðə wɪmən læft əɡɛn, ən feɪl ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɹæn bæk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp, waɪt ɹoʊbz swɪʃɪŋ. ʃi kɹɪnʒd ət ðə θɔɾ ə hævɪŋ tə wɛɹ sətʃ kloʊðɪŋ əɡɛn, ɪf oʊnli kəz ɪt meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk əbaʊɾ əɹ deɪz ə sɝvəs tə sɪvænə.

The women laughed again, and Faile shook her head as they ran back toward the camp, white robes swishing. She cringed at the thought of having to wear such clothing again, if only because it made her think about her days of service to Sevanna.

læŋki ɹɛlə ən ɡɹeɪsfəl lətʃəl dʒɔɪn əɹ ət ðə beɪs ə ðə tu wɪloʊz. ðə meɪɾən ɡɑɹdz steɪd bɪhaɪnd, wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm əfɑɹ. ə θɝd meɪɾən dʒɔɪn ðoʊz tu, muvɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz, laɪkli sɛn baɪ beɪn ən kiæd tə pɹətɛkt æliændɝ. feɪl faʊn ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹd kwin stændɪŋ ət ðə beɪs ə ðə tʃɹiz, lʊkɪŋ laɪk ə leɪɾi əɡɛn ɪn ə ɹɪtʃ ɹɛd ɡaʊn wɪð ɡoʊldən tʃeɪnz lɑsɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ. ɪt wɑz ən ɪkstʃɹævəɡən dɪspleɪ, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ dɪtɝmən tə dɪspɹuv ðə deɪz ʃid spɛn æktɪŋ əz ə sɝvənt. æliændɝz ɡaʊn meɪd feɪl mɔɹ əwɛɹ ə hɝ sɪmpəl ɹoʊb. bʌt ðəɹ wɑzn mʌtʃ ʃi cʊɾə dʌn wɪθaʊt weɪkɪŋ pɛɹɪn. ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl wɔɹ oʊnli ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd bɹitʃɪz ən ʃɝts kɑmən tə ðoʊz ɪn tʃɑ feɪl.

Lanky Arrela and graceful Lacile joined her at the base of the two willows. The Maiden guards stayed behind, watching from afar. A third Maiden joined those two, moving out of the shadows, likely sent by Bain and Chiad to protect Alliandre. Faile found the dark-haired queen standing at the base of the trees, looking like a lady again in a rich red gown with golden chains lacing her hair. It was an extravagant display, as if she were determined to disprove the days she'd spent acting as a servant. Alliandre's gown made Faile more aware of her simple robe. But there wasn't much she could have done without waking Perrin. Arrela and Lacile wore only the embroidered breeches and shirts common to those in Cha Faile.

æliændɝ kæɹiɾ ə smɔl læntɝn wɪð ðə ʃʌɾɝz dʒɹɔn, lɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ oʊnli ə kɹæk ə laɪt ðəɾ ɪluməneɪɾəd əɹ juθfəl feɪs, tɑp baɪ dɑɹk hɛɹ. "dɪd ðeɪ faɪn ɛniθɪŋ?" ʃi æskt. "pliz tɛl mi ðət ðeɪ dɪd." ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ɪmpɹɛsɪvli ɡɹaʊndɪd, fəɹ ə kwin, ɪf sʌmwʌt dɪmændɪŋ.

Alliandre carried a small lantern with the shutters drawn, letting out only a crack of light that illuminated her youthful face, topped by dark hair. "Did they find anything?" she asked. "Please tell me that they did." She had always been impressively grounded, for a queen, if somewhat demanding.

hɝ taɪm ɪn mɔldən sim tə hæv tɛmpɝd ðə læɾɝ fitʃɝ.

Her time in Malden seemed to have tempered the latter feature.

"jɛs." feɪl hɛftəd ðə bʌndəl. ðə fɔɹ wɪmən hʌɾəld ɝaʊn əɹ əz ʃi nɛlt ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðə tɪps ə ðə ʃɔɹt ɡɹæs lɪt baɪ ðə læntɝn, ʃaɪnɪŋ laɪk tʌŋz ə fleɪm. feɪl ənɹæp ðə bʌndəl.

"Yes." Faile hefted the bundle. The four women huddled around her as she knelt on the ground, the tips of the short grass lit by the lantern, shining like tongues of flame. Faile unwrapped the bundle.

ðə kɑntɛns wɝn ɛniθɪŋ ɪkstʃɹɔɹɾənɛɹi. ə smɔl hæŋkɝtʃɪf ə jɛloʊ sɪlk. ə bɛlt ʌv wɝk lɛðɝ wɪtʃ hæɾ ə pæɾɝn ə bɝd fɛðɝz pɹɛst ɪndə ɪts saɪdz. ə blæk veɪl. ən ə θɪn lɛðɝ bænd wɪð ə stoʊn taɪɾ ət ðə sɛntɝ.

The contents weren't anything extraordinary. A small handkerchief of yellow silk. A belt of worked leather which had a pattern of bird feathers pressed into its sides. A black veil. And a thin leather band with a stone tied at the center.

"ðæt bɛl bɪlɔŋ tə kɪnhuən," æliændɝ sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ɪt. "aɪ sɔ hɪm wɛɹɪŋ ɪt, bɪfɔɹ. . . ."

"That belt belonged to Kinhuin," Alliandre said, pointing to it. "I saw him wearing it, before. . . ."

ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, ðən nɛlt ən pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp.

She trailed off, then knelt and picked it up.

"ðə veɪl ɪz ðəɾ ʌv ə meɪɾən," ɹɛlə sɛd.

"The veil is that of a Maiden," Arrela said.

"ðeɪɹ dɪfɹənt?" æliændɝ æskt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz.

"They're different?" Alliandre asked with surprise.

"ʌv kɔɹs ðeɪ ɑɹ," ɹɛlə sɛd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə veɪl. feɪl hæd nɛvɝ mɛt ðə meɪɾən u hæd bɪkʌm ɹɛləz pɹətɛktɝ, bʌt ðə wʊmən hæd fɔlən ɪn ðə bæɾəl, ðoʊ nɑɾ əz dʒɹəmæɾɪkli əz ɹoʊlən ən ði ʌðɝz.

"Of course they are," Arrela said, picking up the veil. Faile had never met the Maiden who had become Arrela's protector, but the woman had fallen in the battle, though not as dramatically as Rolan and the others.

ðə pis ə sɪlk wɑz ɔɝeɪɾɪnz; lətʃəl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən tʊk ɪɾ ɪn əɹ hænz, tɝnɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ən ɹɪvilɪŋ ðət ðəɹ wɑz ə spɑɾ ə blʌɾ ɑn ɪt. ðət lɛft oʊnli ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹd. ɹoʊlən hæd wɔɹn ɪɾ əɾ ɪz nɛk, ɑn əkeɪʒən, bɪniθ ɪz keɪɾɪnsɝ. feɪl wʌndɝd wʌɾ ɪt hæd mɛn tə hɪm, ən ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛni səɡnɪfɪkəns tə ðə sɪŋɡəl bɪɾ ə stoʊn, ə ɹʌf-kʌt tʃʌŋk ə tɝkwɔɪz. ʃi pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp, ðən ɡlænst ət lətʃəl. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðə slɛndɝ wʊmən sim tə bi kɹaɪɪŋ. kəz lətʃəl hæd ɡɔn soʊ kwɪkli tə ðə hɛfti bɹʌðɝləsəz bɛd, feɪl hæɾ əsum ðəɾ əɹ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp wɪð ɪm hæd bɪn wʌn ə nəsɛsəɾi, nɑɾ əfɛkʃən.

The piece of silk was Jhoradin's; Lacile hesitated, then took it in her hands, turning it over and revealing that there was a spot of blood on it. That left only the leather cord. Rolan had worn it at his neck, on occasion, beneath his cadin'sor. Faile wondered what it had meant to him, and if there was any significance to the single bit of stone, a rough-cut chunk of turquoise. She picked it up, then glanced at Lacile. Surprisingly, the slender woman seemed to be crying. Because Lacile had gone so quickly to the hefty Brotherless's bed, Faile had assumed that her relationship with him had been one of necessity, not affection.

"fɔɹ pipəl ɑɹ dɛd," feɪl sɛd, maʊθ sʌɾənli dʒɹaɪ. ʃi spoʊk fɔɹməli, fəɹ ðət wɑz ðə bɛst weɪ tə kip ði ɪmoʊʃən fɹəm əɹ vɔɪs. "ðeɪ pɹətɛktəɾ ʌs, ivən kɛɹd fəɹ ʌs. ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ ði ɛnəmi, wi mɔɹn ðɛm. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ðoʊ, ðət ðeɪ wɝ il. fəɹ ən il, ðəɹ ɑɹ fɑɹ wɝs ɛnz ðən dɛθ ɪn kɑmbæt."

"Four people are dead," Faile said, mouth suddenly dry. She spoke formally, for that was the best way to keep the emotion from her voice. "They protected us, even cared for us. Though they were the enemy, we mourn them. Remember, though, that they were Aiel. For an Aiel, there are far worse ends than death in combat."

ði ʌðɝz nɑɾəd, bʌt lətʃəl mɛt feɪlz aɪz. fəɹ ðə tu ʌv ðɛm, ɪt wɑz dɪfɹənt. wən pɛɹɪn hæd bæɹəld aʊɾ ə ðəɾ æliweɪ - ɹɔɹɪŋ ɪn æŋɡɝ ət siɪŋ feɪl ən lətʃəl əpɛɹənli biɪŋ mænhændəl baɪ ʃeɪɾoʊ - mɛni θɪŋz hæd hæpən vɛɹi kwɪkli. ɪn ðə fɹeɪ, feɪl hæd dɪstʃɹæktəd ɹoʊlən ət dʒʌs ðə ɹaɪt moʊmənt, meɪkɪŋ ɪm hɛzəteɪt. hid dʌn soʊ aʊɾ ə kənsɝn fəɹ hɝ, bʌt ðət pɔz hæɾ əlaʊd pɛɹɪn tə kɪl hɪm.

The others nodded, but Lacile met Faile's eyes. For the two of them, it was different. When Perrin had barreled out of that alleyway - roaring in anger at seeing Faile and Lacile apparently being manhandled by Shaido - many things had happened very quickly. In the fray, Faile had distracted Rolan at just the right moment, making him hesitate. He'd done so out of concern for her, but that pause had allowed Perrin to kill him.

hæd feɪl dʌn ɪɾ ɪntɛnʃənəli? ʃi stɪl dɪdnt noʊ. soʊ mʌtʃ hæd bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu hɝ maɪnd, soʊ mɛni ɪmoʊʃənz ət siɪŋ pɛɹɪn. ʃid kɹaɪɾ aʊt, ən . . . ʃi kəd nɑt dɪsaɪɾ ɪf ʃid bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪstʃɹækt ɹoʊlən tə lɛɾ ɪm daɪ baɪ pɛɹɪnz hænd.

Had Faile done it intentionally? She still didn't know. So much had been going through her mind, so many emotions at seeing Perrin. She'd cried out, and . . . she could not decide if she'd been trying to distract Rolan to let him die by Perrin's hand.

fəɹ lətʃəl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sətʃ weɪvɝɪŋ. ɔɝeɪɾɪn hæd lɛpt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, pʊɾɪŋ əɹ bɪhaɪn ɪm ən ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz wɛpən əɡɛns ði ɪntʃɹuɾɝ. ʃid pʊɾ ə naɪf ɪn ɪz bæk, kɪlɪŋ ə mæn fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn əɹ laɪf. ən ɪt hæd bɪn ə mæn huz bɛd ʃid ʃɛɹd.

For Lacile, there was no such wavering. Jhoradin had leaped in front of her, putting her behind him and raising his weapon against the intruder. She'd put a knife in his back, killing a man for the first time in her life. And it had been a man whose bed she'd shared.

feɪl hæd kɪl kɪnhuən, ði ʌðɝ mɛmbɝ ə ðə bɹʌðɝləs u hæd pɹətɛktəd ðɛm. hi wɑzn ðə fɝs mæn huz laɪf ʃi hæd teɪkən - nɔɹ ðə fɝst wʌn ʃid teɪkən fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. bʌɾ i wɑz ðə fɝs mæn ʃid kɪld u hæd sin əɹ əz ə fɹɛnd.

Faile had killed Kinhuin, the other member of the Brotherless who had protected them. He wasn't the first man whose life she had taken - nor the first one she'd taken from behind. But he was the first man she'd killed who had seen her as a friend.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls ðət cʊɾə bɪn dʌn. pɛɹɪn hæd sin oʊnli ʃeɪɾoʊ, ən ðə bɹʌðɝləs hæd sin oʊnli ən ɪnveɪɾɪŋ ɛnəmi. ðət kɑnflɪkt kəd nɑɾ əv ɛndəd wɪθaʊt pɛɹɪn əɹ ðə bɹʌðɝləs dɛd. noʊ əmaʊn ə skɹimɪŋ wʊɾə stɑpt ɛni ʌv ðə mɛn.

There was nothing else that could have been done. Perrin had seen only Shaido, and the Brotherless had seen only an invading enemy. That conflict could not have ended without Perrin or the Brotherless dead. No amount of screaming would have stopped any of the men.

bʌt ðət meɪɾ ɪt mɔɹ tʃɹædʒɪk. feɪl stil hɝsɛlf tə kip əɹ aɪz fɹəm tɛɹɪŋ ʌp laɪk lətʃəlz.

But that made it more tragic. Faile steeled herself to keep her eyes from tearing up like Lacile's.

ʃi hædn lʌvd ɹoʊlən, ən ʃi wɑz ɡlæd ðət pɛɹɪn wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd sɝvaɪv ðə kɑnflɪkt. bʌt ɹoʊlən hæd bɪn ən ɑnɝəbəl mæn, ən ʃi fɛlt . . . dɝɾid, sʌmhaʊ, ðəɾ ɪz dɛθ hæd bɪn əɹ fɔlt.

She hadn't loved Rolan, and she was glad that Perrin was the one who had survived the conflict. But Rolan had been an honorable man, and she felt . . . dirtied, somehow, that his death had been her fault.

ðɪs ʃʊdn əv hæd tə bi. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz. hɝ fɑðɝ hæɾ ɔfən spoʊkən ə sɪtʃueɪʃənz laɪk ðɪs, wən jə hæd tə kɪl pipəl jə laɪk dʒʌs kəz jə mɛɾ əm ɑn ðə ɹɔŋ saɪɾ ə ðə bæɾəlfild. ʃid nɛvɝ ʌndɝstʊd. ɪf ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ bæk ən də ɪɾ əɡɛn, ʃi wəd teɪk ðə vɛɹi seɪm ækʃənz. ʃi wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə ɹɪsk pɛɹɪn. ɹoʊlən hæd hæd tə daɪ.

This shouldn't have had to be. But it was. Her father had often spoken of situations like this, when you had to kill people you liked just because you met them on the wrong side of the battlefield. She'd never understood. If she had to go back and do it again, she would take the very same actions. She wouldn't be able to risk Perrin. Rolan had had to die.

bʌt ðə wɝl simd ə sæɾɝ pleɪs tə hɝ fəɹ ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv ɪt.

But the world seemed a sadder place to her for the necessity of it.

lətʃəl tɝn əweɪ, snɪfəlɪŋ sɔfli. feɪl nɛlt, teɪkɪŋ ə smɔl flæsk ʌv ɔɪl fɹəm ðə bʌndəl kiæd hæd lɛft. ʃi tʊk ðə lɛðɝ stʃɹæp ən pʊld ɔf ðə stoʊn, ðən sɛt ðə stʃɹæp ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə klɔθ bʌndəl. ʃi pɔɹd ði ɔɪl ɑn ɪt, ðən juzd ə tɪndɝ stɪk, lɪɾ ət ðə læntɝn, tə sɛt ðə stʃɹæp əfaɪɹ.

Lacile turned away, sniffling softly. Faile knelt, taking a small flask of oil from the bundle Chiad had left. She took the leather strap and pulled off the stone, then set the strap in the center of the cloth bundle. She poured the oil on it, then used a tinder stick, lit at the lantern, to set the strap afire.

ʃi wɑtʃt ɪt bɝn, taɪni lɪɾəl fleɪmz ə blu ən ɡɹin, tɑp baɪ ɔɹənʒ. ðə sɛn ə bɝnɪŋ lɛðɝ wɑz ʃɑkɪŋli sɪməlɝ tə ðəɾ ə bɝnɪŋ hjumən flɛʃ. ðə naɪt wɑz stɪl, noʊ wɪn tə ʃeɪk ðə fleɪmz, ən soʊ ðeɪ dæns fɹili.

She watched it burn, tiny little flames of blue and green, topped by orange. The scent of burning leather was shockingly similar to that of burning human flesh. The night was still, no wind to shake the flames, and so they danced freely.

æliændɝ daʊs ðə bɛlt ən pʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn tə ðə mɪniətʃʊɹ faɪɝ. ɹɛlə dɪd ðə seɪm wɪð ðə veɪl.

Alliandre doused the belt and put it on to the miniature fire. Arrela did the same with the veil.

faɪnəli, lətʃəl æɾəd ðə hæŋkɝtʃɪf. ʃi wɑz stɪl kɹaɪɪŋ.

Finally, Lacile added the handkerchief. She was still crying.

ðɪs wɑz ɔl ðeɪ kəd du. ðəɹ hædn bɪn ə weɪ tə si tə ðə bɑɾiz ɪn ðə keɪɑs ə livɪŋ mɔldən. kiæd hæd sɛd ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dɪsɑnɝ ɪn livɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt feɪl hæd niɾəd tə də sʌmθɪŋ.

This was all they could do. There hadn't been a way to see to the bodies in the chaos of leaving Malden. Chiad had said there was no dishonor in leaving them, but Faile had needed to do something.

səm smɔl weɪ ʌv ɑnɝɪŋ ɹoʊlən ən ði ʌðɝz.

Some small way of honoring Rolan and the others.

"dɛd baɪ əɹ hænd," feɪl sɛd, "ɔɹ sɪmpli dɛd fɹəm bæɾəl, ðiz fɔɹ ʃoʊɾ əs ɑnɝ. əz ði il wəd seɪ, wɪv ɡɹeɪt toʊ tə ðɛm. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɪt kən bi ɹipeɪd. bʌt wi kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɛm.

"Dead by our hand," Faile said, "or simply dead from battle, these four showed us honor. As the Aiel would say, we have great toh to them. I don't think it can be repaid. But we can remember them.

ðə bɹʌðɝləs ən wʌn meɪɾən ʃoʊɾ əs kaɪndnəs wən ðeɪ dɪdnt nid tə. ðeɪ kɛp ðɛɹ ɑnɝ wən ʌðɝz hæɾ əbændən ɪt. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ə ɹɪdɛmpʃən tə bi faʊn fəɹ ðɛm, ən fəɹ ʌs, ðɪs wɪl bi ɪt."

The Brotherless and one Maiden showed us kindness when they didn't need to. They kept their honor when others had abandoned it. If there is a redemption to be found for them, and for us, this will be it."

"ðɛɹz ə bɹʌðɝləs ɪn pɛɹɪnz kæmp," lətʃəl sɛd, aɪz ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə fleɪmz ə ðɛɹ paɪɹ.

"There's a Brotherless in Perrin's camp," Lacile said, eyes reflecting the flames of their pyre.

"naɪəɡən ɪz ɪz neɪm; hiz ɡeɪʃeɪn tə səlɪn, ðə meɪɾən. aɪ wɛn tə tɛl ɪm ʌv wʌt ði ʌðɝz dɪd fəɹ ʌs. hiz ə kaɪn mæn."

"Niagen is his name; he is gai'shain to Sulin, the Maiden. I went to tell him of what the others did for us. He is a kind man."

feɪl kloʊzd əɹ aɪz. lətʃəl pɹɑbli mɛn ðət ʃi hæd ɡɔn tə ðə bɛɾ ə ðɪs naɪəɡən. ðət wɑzn fɔɹbɪɾən ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn. "ju kæn ɹipleɪs ɔɝeɪɾɪn laɪk ðæt," ʃi sɛd, oʊpənɪŋ əɹ aɪz.

Faile closed her eyes. Lacile probably meant that she had gone to the bed of this Niagen. That wasn't forbidden of gai'shain. "You can't replace Jhoradin like that," she said, opening her eyes.

"ɔɹ əndu wʌt jə dɪd."

"Or undo what you did."

"aɪ noʊ," lətʃəl sɛd dɪfɛnsɪvli. "bʌt ðeɪ wɝ soʊ fʊl ə hjumɝ, dɪspaɪt ðə tɛɹəbəl sɪtʃueɪʃən.

"I know," Lacile said defensively. "But they were so full of humor, despite the terrible situation.

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm. ɔɝeɪɾɪn wɑntəd tə teɪk mi bæk tə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd, meɪk mi hɪz waɪf."

There was something about them. Jhoradin wanted to take me back to the Three-fold Land, make me his wife."

ən jud nɛvɝ əv dʌn ɪt, feɪl θɔt. aɪ noʊ jə wʊdn hæv. bʌt naʊ ðət hiz dɛd, jə ɹilaɪz ði ɑpɝtunəɾi jə lɔst.

And you'd never have done it, Faile thought. I know you wouldn't have. But now that he's dead, you realize the opportunity you lost.

wɛl, hu wɑz ʃi tə tʃæstaɪz? lɛt lətʃəl də əz ʃi wɪʃt. ɪf ðɪs naɪəɡən wɑz hæf ðə mæn ðət ɹoʊlən əɹ ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn, ðən pɝhæps lətʃəl wəd də wɛl wɪð hɪm.

Well, who was she to chastise? Let Lacile do as she wished. If this Niagen was half the man that Rolan or the others had been, then perhaps Lacile would do well with him.

"kɪnhuən hæɾ oʊnli dʒʌst stɑɹɾəd lʊkɪŋ aʊt fəɹ mi," æliændɝ sɛd. "aɪ noʊ wʌɾ i wɪʃt fɔɹ, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ dɪmændəɾ ɪt. aɪ θɪŋk i wɑz plænɪŋ tə liv ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ən wʊɾə hɛlpt əs ɪskeɪp. ivən ɪf aɪ tɝn ɪm daʊn, hi wʊɾə hɛlpt ʌs."

"Kinhuin had only just started looking out for me," Alliandre said. "I know what he wished for, but he never demanded it. I think he was planning to leave the Shaido, and would have helped us escape. Even if I turned him down, he would have helped us."

"mɑɹθiə heɪɾəd wʌt ði ʌðɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪd," ɹɛlə sɛd. "bʌt ʃi steɪd wɪð əm fəɹ əɹ klæn.

"Marthea hated what the other Shaido did," Arrela said. "But she stayed with them for her clan.

ʃi daɪd fəɹ ðət lɔɪəlti. ðəɹ ɑɹ wɝs θɪŋz tə daɪ fɔɹ."

She died for that loyalty. There are worse things to die for."

feɪl wɑtʃt ðə læst ɛmbɝz ə ðə mɪniətʃʊɹ paɪɹ flɪkɝ aʊt. "aɪ θɪŋk ɹoʊlən æktʃəli  lʌv mi,"

Faile watched the last embers of the miniature pyre flicker out. "I think Rolan actually loved me,"

ʃi sɛd. ən ðət wɑz ɔl.

she said. And that was all.

ðə fɔɹ ɹoʊz ən ɹɪtɝn tə ðə kæmp. ðə pæst wɑz ə fild ʌv ɛmbɝz ən æʃ, ən oʊl sɑldəiən pɹoʊvɝb sɛd, ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðə faɪɝ ðət wɑz ðə pɹɛzənt. ðoʊz ɛmbɝz blu əweɪ bɪhaɪn hɝ. bʌt ʃi kɛpt ɹoʊlənz tɝkwɔɪz stoʊn. nɑt fəɹ ɹəɡɹɛt, bʌt fəɹ ɹimɛmbɹəns.

The four rose and returned to the camp. The past was a field of embers and ash, an old Saldaean proverb said, the remnants of the fire that was the present. Those embers blew away behind her. But she kept Rolan's turquoise stone. Not for regret, but for remembrance.

pɛɹɪn leɪ əweɪk ɪn ðə stɪl naɪt, smɛlɪŋ ðə kænvəs ə hɪz tɛn ən ðə junik sɛn ə feɪl.

Perrin lay awake in the still night, smelling the canvas of his tent and the unique scent of Faile.

ʃi wɑzn ðɛɹ, ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn ɹisənli. hid doʊzd ɔf, ən naʊ ʃi wɑz ɡɔn. pɝhæps tə ðə pɹɪvi.

She wasn't there, though she had been recently. He'd dozed off, and now she was gone. Perhaps to the privy.

hi stɛɹɾ ʌp ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk sɛns ə hɑpɝ ən ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. ðə mɔɹ i θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ðə mɔɹ dɪtɝmən i ɡɹu. hi wəd mɑɹtʃ tə ðə læs bæɾəl - ən wən i dɪd, hi wɑntəd tə bi eɪbəl tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə wʊlf ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm. hi wɑntəɾ iðɝ tə bi fɹi ʌv ɔl ə ðiz pipəl u fɑloʊd hɪm, əɹ tə lɝn haʊ tə æksɛp ðɛɹ lɔɪəlti.

He stared up in the darkness, trying to make sense of Hopper and the wolf dream. The more he thought about it, the more determined he grew. He would march to the Last Battle - and when he did, he wanted to be able to control the wolf inside of him. He wanted either to be free of all of these people who followed him, or to learn how to accept their loyalty.

hi hæd səm dɪsɪʒənz tə meɪk. ðeɪ wʊdn bi izi, bʌt hid meɪk ðɛm. ə mæn hæd tə də hɑɹd θɪŋz. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ ʌv laɪf. ðət wɑz wʌt hæd ɡɔn ɹɔŋ wɪð ðə weɪ hid hændəl feɪlz kæptʃɝ. ɪnstɛɾ ə meɪkɪŋ dɪsɪʒənz, hiɾ əvɔɪɾəd ðɛm. mæstɝ luhən wʊɾə bɪn dɪsəpɔɪntɪɾ ɪn hɪm.

He had some decisions to make. They wouldn't be easy, but he'd make them. A man had to do hard things. That was the way of life. That was what had gone wrong with the way he'd handled Faile's capture. Instead of making decisions, he'd avoided them. Master Luhhan would have been disappointed in him.

ən ðət lɛd pɛɹɪn tə ənʌðɝ dɪsɪʒən, ðə hɑɹɾəst ʌv ɔl. hi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə lɛt feɪl ɹaɪɾ ɪndə deɪnʒɝ, pɝhæps ɹɪsk əɹ əɡɛn. wɑz ðəɾ ə dɪsɪʒən? kəɾ i meɪk sətʃ ə dɪsɪʒən? ðə mɪɹ θɔɾ ə hɝ ɪn deɪnʒɝ meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə sɪk ʌp. bʌɾ i wəɾ əv tə də sʌmθɪŋ.

And that led Perrin to another decision, the hardest of all. He was going to have to let Faile ride into danger, perhaps risk her again. Was that a decision? Could he make such a decision? The mere thought of her in danger made him want to sick up. But he would have to do something.

θɹi pɹɑbləmz. hi wəd feɪs əm ən i wəd dɪsaɪd. bʌɾ i wəd kənsɪɾɝ əm fɝst, kəz ðət wɑz wʌɾ i dɪd. ə mæn wɑz ə ful tə meɪk dɪsɪʒənz wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ fɝst.

Three problems. He would face them and he would decide. But he would consider them first, because that was what he did. A man was a fool to make decisions without thinking first.

bʌt ðə dɪsɪʒən tə feɪs ɪz pɹɑbləmz bɹɔɾ ɪm ə mɛʒɝ ə pis, ən i ɹoʊld oʊvɝ ən dʒɹɪftəd bæk tə slip.

But the decision to face his problems brought him a measure of peace, and he rolled over and drifted back to sleep.

tʃæptɝ twɛntiɾu

CHAPTER 22

ðə læs ðət kəd bi dʌn sɛmɝhɪdʒ sæɾ əloʊn ɪn ðə smɔl ɹum. ðeɪ hæd teɪkən əweɪ hɝ tʃɛɹ ən ɡɪvən əɹ noʊ læntɝn əɹ kændəl.

The Last That Could Be Done Semirhage sat alone in the small room. They had taken away her chair and given her no lantern or candle.

blæs ðɪs kɝst eɪdʒ ən ɪts kɝs pipəl! wʌt ʃi wʊɾə ɡɪvən fəɹ ɡloʊbəlbz ɑn ðə wɔlz. dʊɹɪŋ əɹ deɪz, pɹɪznɝz hædn bɪn dɪnaɪd laɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd lɑk sɛvɹəl ə hɝ ɪkspɛɹəməns əweɪ ɪn toʊɾəl dɑɹknəs, bʌt ðət wɑz dɪfɹənt. ɪt hæd bɪn ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə dɪskʌvɝ wʌɾ ɪfɛk ðə læk ə laɪt wəɾ əv ɑn ðɛm. ðiz soʊ-kɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hɛl hɝ, ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɹæʃənəl ɹizən fəɹ livɪŋ əɹ ɪn dɑɹknəs. ðeɪ dʒʌs dɪɾ ɪt tə hjumɪlieɪt hɝ.

Blast this cursed Age and its cursed people! What she would have given for glowbulbs on the walls. During her days, prisoners hadn't been denied light. Of course, she had locked several of her experiments away in total darkness, but that was different. It had been important to discover what effect the lack of light would have on them. These so-called Aes Sedai who held her, they had no rational reason for leaving her in darkness. They just did it to humiliate her.

ʃi pʊld əɹ ɑɹmz kloʊsɝ, hʌɾəlɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wʊɾən wɔl. ʃi dɪd nɑt kɹaɪ. ʃi wɑz ə ðə tʃoʊzən! soʊ wʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə əbeɪs hɝsɛlf? ʃi wɑz nɑt bɹoʊkən.

She pulled her arms closer, huddling against the wooden wall. She did not cry. She was of the Chosen! So what if she had been forced to abase herself? She was not broken.

bʌt . . . ðə ful ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ əz ðeɪ hæd. sɛmɝhɪdʒ hædn tʃeɪnʒd, bʌt ðeɪ hæd. sʌmhaʊ, ɪn wʌn swup, ðət kɝst wʊmən wɪð ðə pɛɹəlis-nɛɾ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ hæɾ ənɹævəl sɛmɝhɪdʒəz əθɔɹəɾi wɪð ði ɪntaɪɝ lɑɾ ə ðɛm.

But . . . the fool Aes Sedai no longer regarded her as they had. Semirhage hadn't changed, but they had. Somehow, in one swoop, that cursed woman with the paralis-net in her hair had unraveled Semirhage's authority with the entire lot of them.

haʊ? haʊ hæd ʃi lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl soʊ kwɪkli? ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd əz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd biɪŋ tɝn oʊvɝ ðə wʊmənz niz ən spæŋkt. ən ðə nɑnʃəlɑns ʌv ɪt. ði oʊnli ɪmoʊʃən ɪn ðə wʊmənz vɔɪs hæd bɪn ə slaɪɾ ənɔɪəns. ʃid tʃɹiɾəd sɛmɝhɪdʒ - wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən! - əz ɪf ʃi wɝ bɛɹli wɝði ʌv noʊɾəs. ðət hæd ɡæl mɔɹ ðən ðə bloʊz.

How? How had she lost control so quickly? She shuddered as she remembered being turned over the woman's knees and spanked. And the nonchalance of it. The only emotion in the woman's voice had been a slight annoyance. She'd treated Semirhage - one of the Chosen! - as if she were barely worthy of notice. That had galled more than the blows.

ɪt wəd nɑt hæpən əɡɛn. sɛmɝhɪdʒ wəd bi ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðə bloʊz nɛks taɪm, ən ʃi wəd ɡɪv əm noʊ weɪt. jɛs, ðət wəd wɝk. wʊdn ɪt?

It would not happen again. Semirhage would be ready for the blows next time, and she would give them no weight. Yes, that would work. Wouldn't it?

ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd əɡɛn. ʃi hæd tɔɹtʃɝd hʌnʒɹədz, pɝhæps θaʊzənz, ɪn ðə neɪm ʌv ʌndɝstændɪŋ ən ɹizən. tɔɹtʃɝ meɪd sɛns. jə tʃɹuli sɔ wʌɾ ə pɝsən wɑz meɪɾ ʌv, ɪn mɔɹ weɪz ðən wʌn, wən jə bɪɡæn tə slaɪs ɪndə ðɛm. ðət wɑz ə fɹeɪz ʃid juzd ɑn numɝəs əkeɪʒənz. ɪt juʒəwəli meɪɾ əɹ smaɪl.

She shuddered again. She had tortured hundreds, perhaps thousands, in the name of understanding and reason. Torture made sense. You truly saw what a person was made of, in more ways than one, when you began to slice into them. That was a phrase she'd used on numerous occasions. It usually made her smile.

ðɪs taɪm ɪt dɪd nɑt.

This time it did not.

waɪ kʊdn ðeɪv ɡɪvən əɹ peɪn? bɹoʊkən fɪŋɡɝz, kʌts ɪndə hɝ flɛʃ, koʊlz ɪn ðə pɪts ə hɝ ɛlboʊz. ʃi hæd stild əɹ maɪn tə itʃ ə ðiz θɪŋz, pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm. ə smɔl, iɡɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɝsɛlf hæd lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ðɛm.

Why couldn't they have given her pain? Broken fingers, cuts into her flesh, coals in the pits of her elbows. She had steeled her mind to each of these things, preparing for them. A small, eager part of herself had looked forward to them.

bʌt ðɪs? biɪŋ fɔɹs tə it fuɾ ɔf ðə flɔɹ? biɪŋ tʃɹiɾəd laɪk ə tʃaɪld ɪn fɹʌn ə ðoʊz u hæd ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ wɪð sətʃ ɑ?

But this? Being forced to eat food off the floor? Being treated like a child in front of those who had regarded her with such awe?

əl kɪl hɝ, ʃi θɔt, nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. əl ɹimuv əɹ tɛndənz, wʌn əɾ ə taɪm, juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ tə hil əɹ soʊ ðət ʃi laɪvz tə ɪkspɪɹiəns ðə peɪn. noʊ. noʊ, əl də sʌmθɪŋ nu tə hɝ. əl ʃoʊ hɝ æɡəni ðət hæzən bɪn noʊn tə ɛniwʌn ɪn ɛni eɪdʒ!

I will kill her, she thought, not for the first time. I will remove her tendons, one at a time, using the Power to heal her so that she lives to experience the pain. No. No, I'll do something new to her. I will show her agony that hasn't been known to anyone in any Age!

"sɛmɝhɪdʒ." ə wɪspɝ.

"Semirhage." A whisper.

ʃi fɹoʊz, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ðət vɔɪs hæd bɪn sɑft, laɪk ə tʃɪl wɪnd, jɛt stɪl ʃɑɹp ən baɪɾɪŋ. hæd ʃi ɪmædʒən ɪt? hi kʊdn bi ðɛɹ, kəd hi?

She froze, looking up in the darkness. That voice had been soft, like a chill wind, yet still sharp and biting. Had she imagined it? He couldn't be there, could he?

"ju hæv feɪld ɡɹeɪtli, sɛmɝhɪdʒ," ðə vɔɪs kəntɪnjud, soʊ sɑft. ə feɪn laɪt ʃoʊn ʌndɝniθ ðə dɔɹ, bʌt ðə vɔɪs keɪm fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ sɛl. ðə laɪt sim tə ɡɹoʊ bɹaɪɾɝ, ən ɪt flʌʃt ə dip ɹɛd, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ðə hɛm ʌv ə fɪɡjɝ ɪn ə blæk kloʊk stændɪŋ bɪfɔɹ hɝ. ʃi lʊkt ʌp. ðə ɹʌɾi laɪt ɹɪvild ə feɪs ʌv waɪt, ðə kʌlɝ ə dɛd skɪn. ðə feɪs hæd noʊ aɪz.

"You have failed greatly, Semirhage," the voice continued, so soft. A faint light shone underneath the door, but the voice came from inside her cell. The light seemed to grow brighter, and it flushed a deep red, illuminating the hem of a figure in a black cloak standing before her. She looked up. The ruddy light revealed a face of white, the color of dead skin. The face had no eyes.

ʃi ɪmiɾiətli nɛl tə ðə flɔɹ, pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɑn ði eɪdʒɪd wʊd. ðoʊ ðə fɪɡjɝ bɪfɔɹ əɹ lʊk laɪk ə mɹdʒɹɑl, ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ tɔlɝ ən mʌtʃ, mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ʃi ʃɪvɝɾ əz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə vɔɪs ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hɪmsɛlf, spikɪŋ tə hɝ.

She immediately knelt to the floor, prostrating herself on the aged wood. Though the figure before her looked like a Myrddraal, it was much taller and much, much more important. She shivered as she remembered the voice of the Great Lord himself, speaking to her.

wən jə oʊbeɪ ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən, jə oʊbeɪ mi. wən jə dɪsəbeɪ. . . .

When you obey Shaidar Haran, you obey me. When you disobey. . . .

"ju wɝ tə kæptʃɝ ðə bɔɪ, nɑt kɪl hɪm," ðə fɪɡjɝ wɪspɝɾ ɪn ə hɪs, laɪk stim ɪskeɪpɪŋ θɹu kɹæks bɪtwin pɑɾ ən lɪd. "ju tʊk ɪz hæn ən nɪɹli hɪz laɪf. juv ɹɪvil jɝsɛlf ən əv lɔs væljəbəl pɔnz. juv bɪn kæptʃɝd baɪ əɹ ɛnəmiz, ən naʊ ðeɪv bɹoʊkən ju." ʃi kəd hɪɹ ðə smaɪl ɑn ɪts lɪps. ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən wɑz ði oʊnli mɹdʒɹɑl ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin bɛɹ ə smaɪl. bʌt, ðɛn, ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðɪs θɪŋ wɑz tʃɹuli ə mɹdʒɹɑl.

"You were to capture the boy, not kill him," the figure whispered in a hiss, like steam escaping through cracks between pot and lid. "You took his hand and nearly his life. You have revealed yourself and have lost valuable pawns. You have been captured by our enemies, and now they have broken you." She could hear the smile on its lips. Shaidar Haran was the only Myrddraal she had ever seen bear a smile. But, then, she did not think this thing was truly a Myrddraal.

ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪplaɪ tə ɪts tʃɑɹdʒəz. wʌn dɪd nɑt laɪ, əɹ ivən meɪk ɪkskjusɪz, bɪfɔɹ ðɪs fɪɡjɝ.

She did not reply to its charges. One did not lie, or even make excuses, before this figure.

sʌɾənli, ðə ʃil blɑkɪŋ əɹ vænɪʃt. hɝ bɹɛθ kɑt. seɪaɪdɑɹ hæd ɹɪtɝnd! swit paʊɝ. haʊɛvɝ, əz ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪt, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðoʊz ɪməteɪʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊtsaɪd wəd fil ɪɾ ɪf ʃi tʃænəld.

Suddenly, the shield blocking her vanished. Her breath caught. Saidar had returned! Sweet power. However, as she reached for it, she hesitated. Those imitation Aes Sedai outside would feel it if she channeled.

ə koʊld, lɔŋ-neɪl hæn tʌtʃt əɹ tʃɪn. ðə flɛʃ ʌv ɪt fɛlt laɪk dɛd lɛðɝ. ɪt ɹoʊteɪɾɪd əɹ feɪs ʌpwɝd tə mit ði aɪləs ɡeɪz. "ju hæv bɪn ɡɪvən wʌn læs tʃæns," ðə mæɡoʊtlaɪk lɪps wɪspɝd. "du. nɑt. feɪl."

A cold, long-nailed hand touched her chin. The flesh of it felt like dead leather. It rotated her face upward to meet the eyeless gaze. "You have been given one last chance," the maggotlike lips whispered. "Do. Not. Fail."

ðə laɪt feɪɾəd. ðə hæn əɾ əɹ tʃɪn wɪθdʒɹu. ʃi kəntɪnjud tə nil, faɪɾɪŋ daʊn tɛɹɝ. wʌn læs tʃæns. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ɔlweɪz ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd feɪljɝ ɪn . . . ɪmædʒənəɾɪv weɪz. ʃi hæd ɡɪvən sətʃ ɹɪwɔɹdz bɪfɔɹ, ən hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə ɹəsiv ðɛm. ðeɪ wəd meɪk ɛni tɔɹtʃɝ əɹ pʌnɪʃmən ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ kəɾ ɪmædʒən lʊk tʃaɪldɪʃ.

The light faded. The hand at her chin withdrew. She continued to kneel, fighting down terror. One last chance. The Great Lord always rewarded failure in . . . imaginative ways. She had given such rewards before, and had no desire to receive them. They would make any torture or punishment these Aes Sedai could imagine look childish.

ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fit, filɪŋ əɹ weɪ ɝaʊn ðə ɹum. ʃi ɹitʃt ðə dɔɹ ænd, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ, tʃɹaɪɾ ɪt.

She forced herself to her feet, feeling her way around the room. She reached the door and, holding her breath, tried it.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd. ʃi slɪpt aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ðə hɪnʒɪz kɹik. aʊtsaɪd, θɹi kɔɹpsəz leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, slʌmp fɹi ʌv ðɛɹ tʃɛɹz. ðə wɪmən u hæd bɪn meɪnteɪnɪŋ əɹ ʃild. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmwʌn ɛls ðɛɹ, nilɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm. wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə wʊmən ɪn ɡɹin, wɪð bɹaʊn hɛɹ, pʊl bæk ɪndə ə teɪl, hɝ hɛd baʊd.

The door opened. She slipped out of the room without letting the hinges creak. Outside, three corpses lay on the ground, slumped free of their chairs. The women who had been maintaining her shield. There was someone else there, kneeling on the floor before the three of them. One of the Aes Sedai. A woman in green, with brown hair, pulled back into a tail, her head bowed.

"aɪ lɪv tə sɝv, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ðə wʊmən wɪspɝd. "aɪ æm ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə tɛl jə ðət ðəɹ ɪz kəmpʌlʃən ɪn maɪ maɪn jə ɑɹ tə ɹimuv."

"I live to serve, Great Mistress," the woman whispered. "I am instructed to tell you that there is Compulsion in my mind you are to remove."

sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ; ʃi hædn ɹilaɪz ðəɹ wɝ ɛni ʌv ðə blæk əmʌŋ ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ. ɹimuvɪŋ kəmpʌlʃən kəɾ əv ə vɛɹi . . . næsti ɪfɛkt ɑn ə pɝsən. ivən ɪf ðə kəmpʌlʃən wɝ wik əɹ sʌɾəl, ðə bɹeɪn kəd bi hɑɹm sɪɹiəsli baɪ ɹimuvɪŋ ɪt. ɪf ðə kəmpʌlʃən wɝ stʃɹɔŋ . . . wɛl, ɪt wɑz kwaɪɾ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ tə wɑtʃ.

Semirhage raised an eyebrow; she hadn't realized there were any of the Black among those Aes Sedai here. Removing Compulsion could have a very . . . nasty effect on a person. Even if the Compulsion were weak or subtle, the brain could be harmed seriously by removing it. If the Compulsion were strong . . . well, it was quite interesting to watch.

"ɔlsoʊ," ðə wʊmən sɛd, hændɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, ɹæpt ɪn klɔθ. "aɪ æm tə ɡɪv jə ðɪs."

"Also," the woman said, handing something forward, wrapped in cloth. "I am to give you this."

ʃi ɹimuv ðə klɔθ, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə dʌl-kʌlɝd mətælɪk kɑlɝ, ən tu bɹeɪslɪts. ðə dɑməneɪʃən bænd. kɹæftɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, stʃɹaɪkɪŋli sɪməlɝ tə ði æɾəm sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd spɛn soʊ mʌtʃ taɪm wɝkɪŋ wɪð.

She removed the cloth, revealing a dull-colored metallic collar, and two bracelets. The Domination Band. Crafted during the Breaking, strikingly similar to the a'dam Semirhage had spent so much time working with.

wɪð ðɪs tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ə meɪl tʃænlɝ kəd bi kəntʃɹoʊld. ə smaɪl faɪnəli bɹoʊk θɹu sɛmɝhɪdʒəz fɪɹ.

With this ter'angreal, a male channeler could be controlled. A smile finally broke through Semirhage's fear.

ɹænd hæɾ oʊnli vɪzəɾəd ðə blaɪɾ ɑn ə sɪŋɡəl əkeɪʒən, ðoʊ hi kəd feɪnli ɹɪmɛmbɝ hævɪŋ kʌm tə ðɪs ɛɹiə ɑn sɛvɹəl əkeɪʒənz, bɪfɔɹ ðə blaɪɾ ɪnfɛktəd ðə lænd. luz θɝɪnz mɛmɹiz.

Rand had only visited the Blight on a single occasion, though he could faintly remember having come to this area on several occasions, before the Blight infected the land. Lews Therin's memories.

nɑɾ ɪz oʊn.

Not his own.

ðə mædmæn tʊk tə hɪsɪŋ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ æŋɡɹəli əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd θɹu ðə sɑldəiən skɹʌb. ivən teɪdeɪʃɝ ɡɹu skɪɾɪʃ əz ðeɪ muv nɔɹθwɝd.

The madman took to hissing and muttering angrily as they rode through the Saldaean scrub. Even Tai'daishar grew skittish as they moved northward.

sɑldɑiə wɑz ə bɹaʊn lændskeɪp ə bɹʌʃlən ən dɑɹk sɔɪl, noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ əz bæɹən əz ði il weɪst, bʌt hɑɹdli ə sɑft əɹ lʌʃ lænd. hoʊmstɛdz wɝ kɑmən, bʌt ðeɪ hæd nɪɹli ðə lʊk ə fɔɹts, ən jʌŋ tʃɪlʒɹən hɛl ðɛmsɛlvz laɪk tʃɹeɪnd wɔɹiɝz. læn hæd wʌns toʊld ɪm ðəɾ əmʌŋ bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, ə bɔɪ bɪkeɪm ə mæn wən i ɝn ðə ɹaɪt tə kæɹi ə sɔɹd.

Saldaea was a brown landscape of brushland and dark soil, nowhere near as barren as the Aiel Waste, but hardly a soft or lush land. Homesteads were common, but they had nearly the look of forts, and young children held themselves like trained warriors. Lan had once told him that among Borderlanders, a boy became a man when he earned the right to carry a sword.

"hæz ɪɾ əkɝd tə ju," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɹændz lɛft, "ðæt wʌt wəɹ duɪŋ hɪɹ kəd kɑnstətuɾ ən ɪnveɪʒən?"

"Has it occurred to you," Ituralde said, riding on Rand's left, "that what we are doing here could constitute an invasion?"

ɹænd nɑɾəd təwɔɹd bæʃɪɹ, hu ɹoʊd θɹu ðə bɹʌʃ ət ɹændz ɹaɪt. "aɪ bɹɪŋ wɪð mi tʃɹups ə ðɛɹ oʊn blʌd," hi sɛd. "ðə sɑldəiənz ɑɹ maɪ ælaɪz."

Rand nodded toward Bashere, who rode through the brush at Rand's right. "I bring with me troops of their own blood," he said. "The Saldaeans are my allies."

bæʃɪɹ læft. "aɪ daʊt ðət ðə kwin wɪl si ɪt ðət weɪ, maɪ fɹɛnd! ɪts bɪn mɛni mʌnθs sɪns aɪ læst æskt əɹ fəɹ ɔɹɾɝz. waɪ, aɪ wʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðət ʃiz dɪmændəd maɪ hɛd baɪ naʊ."

Bashere laughed. "I doubt that the Queen will see it that way, my friend! It's been many months since I last asked her for orders. Why, I wouldn't be surprised to find that she's demanded my head by now."

ɹænd tɝn ɪz aɪz fɔɹwɝd. "aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪts nɑɾ ən ɪnveɪʒən tə mɑɹtʃ əɡɛns ðə fɔɹsɪz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn." əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ɹoʊz ðə fʊthɪlz ə ðə maʊntənz ə dum. ðeɪ hæɾ ə dɑɹk kæst, əz ɪf ðɛɹ sloʊps wɝ koʊɾəd wɪð sʊt.

Rand turned his eyes forward. "I am the Dragon Reborn. It is not an invasion to march against the forces of the Dark One." Ahead of them rose the foothills of the Mountains of Dhoom. They had a dark cast, as if their slopes were coated with soot.

wʌt wəɾ i hɪmsɛlf də ɪf ənʌðɝ mɑnɑɹk juzd ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə dəpɑzɪt nɪɹli fɪfti θaʊzən tʃɹups wɪðɪn ɪz bɔɹɾɝz? ɪt wɑz ən ækt ʌv wɔɹ, bʌt ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz' fɔɹsɪz wɝ əweɪ duɪŋ laɪɾ oʊnli nu wʌt, ən i wəd nɑt liv ðiz lænz ʌndɪfɛndəd. dʒʌst ən aʊɝz ɹaɪd tə ðə saʊθ, ɪɾɝɑldiz dəmɑni hæd sɛɾ ʌp ə fɔɹɾəfaɪd kæmp bɪsaɪɾ ə ɹɪvɝ ðət hæɾ ɪts sɔɹs ʌp ɪn ðə haɪlənz ʌv wɝlz ɛnd. ɹænd hæɾ ɪnspɛktɪd ðɛɹ kæmp ən ɹæŋks. æftɝ ðæt, bæʃɪɹ hæd sədʒɛstəd ðət ɹænd ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ɪnspɛk ðə blaɪt. ðə skaʊts hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ kwɪkli ðə blaɪt wɑz ədvænsɪŋ, ən bæʃɪɹ θɔɾ ɪɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðəɾ ɪɾɝɑldi ən ɹænd si fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz. ɹænd əɡɹid. mæps səmtaɪmz kʊdn kənveɪ ðə tʃɹuθ aɪz kəd si.

What would he himself do if another monarch used a gateway to deposit nearly fifty thousand troops within his borders? It was an act of war, but the Borderlanders' forces were away doing Light only knew what, and he would not leave these lands undefended. Just an hour's ride to the south, Ituralde's Domani had set up a fortified camp beside a river that had its source up in the highlands of World's End. Rand had inspected their camp and ranks. After that, Bashere had suggested that Rand ride up to inspect the Blight. The scouts had been surprised at how quickly the Blight was advancing, and Bashere thought it important that Ituralde and Rand see for themselves. Rand agreed. Maps sometimes couldn't convey the truth eyes could see.

ðə sʌn wɑz dɪpɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən laɪk ə dʒɹupɪŋ aɪ lɔŋɪŋ fəɹ slip. teɪdeɪʃɝ stæmpt ə huf, tɔsɪŋ ɪz hɛd. ɹænd ɹeɪzd ə hænd, hɔltɪŋ ɪz ɡɹup - tu dʒɛnɝəlz, fɪfti soʊlʒɝz ən ən ikwəl nʌmbɝ ə meɪɾənz, wɪð nɛɹɪʃmə ət ðə bæk tə wiv ɡeɪtweɪz.

The sun was dipping toward the horizon like a drooping eye longing for sleep. Tai'daishar stamped a hoof, tossing his head. Rand raised a hand, halting his group - two generals, fifty soldiers and an equal number of Maidens, with Narishma at the back to weave gateways.

nɔɹθwɝd, ɑn ðə ʃæloʊ sloʊp, ə skɹʌb ə bɹɔd-bleɪɾɪd ɡɹæsəz ən skwɑt bɹʌʃ sweɪd laɪk weɪvz ɪn ðə wɪnd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ spəsɪfɪk laɪn wɛɹ ðə blaɪt bɪɡæn. ə spɑɾ ɑn ə bleɪd ðɛɹ, ə sɪkli kæs tə ə stɛm ðɛɹ. itʃ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl spɛk wɑz ɪnəsənt, jɛt ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni, fɑɹ tu mɛni. ət ðə tɑp ə ðə hɪlsaɪd, nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl plænt wɑz fɹi ʌv ðə spɑts. ðə pɑks sim tə fɛstɝ ivən əz i wɑtʃt.

Northward, on the shallow slope, a scrub of broad-bladed grasses and squat brush swayed like waves in the wind. There was no specific line where the Blight began. A spot on a blade there, a sickly cast to a stem there. Each individual speck was innocent, yet there were too many, far too many. At the top of the hillside, not a single plant was free of the spots. The pox seemed to fester even as he watched.

ðəɹ wɑz ən ɔɪli sɛns ə dɛθ tə ðə blaɪt, ʌv plæns bɛɹli sɝvaɪvɪŋ, kɛpt əlaɪv laɪk pɹɪznɝz stɑɹv tə ðə vɛɹi ɛdʒ ə mɔɹtæləɾi. ɪf ɹænd hæd sin ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs bæk ɪn ə fild ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, hi wʊɾə bɝn ði ɪntaɪɝ kɹɑp, ən wʊɾə bɪn sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ ɪt hædn bɪn dʌn ɔlɹɛɾi.

There was an oily sense of death to the Blight, of plants barely surviving, kept alive like prisoners starved to the very edge of mortality. If Rand had seen anything like this back in a field in the Two Rivers, he would have burnt the entire crop, and would have been surprised that it hadn't been done already.

tə hɪz saɪd, bæʃɪɹ nʌkəld ɪz lɔŋ, dɑɹk mʌstæʃɪz. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən ɪt dɪdn stɑɹt fəɹ ənʌðɝ fju liɡz," hi noʊɾəd. "ðæt wɑzn soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ."

To his side, Bashere knuckled his long, dark mustaches. "I remember when it didn't start for another few leagues," he noted. "That wasn't so long ago."

"aɪ hæv pətʃɹoʊlz ɹʌnɪŋ ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd. hi stɛɹɾ aʊɾ ət ðə sɪkli lændskeɪp. "ɔl ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ɑɹ ðə seɪm. ɪts kwaɪəɾ aʊt ðɛɹ."

"I have patrols running the length of it already," Ituralde said. He stared out at the sickly landscape. "All the reports are the same. It's quiet out there."

"ðæt ʃəd bi ɪnʌf wɔɹnɪŋ ðət sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ," bæʃɪɹ sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz pətʃɹoʊlz əɹ ɹeɪdz ə tʃɹɑləks tə faɪt. ɪf nɑt ðæt, ðən sʌmθɪŋ wɝs, tə skɛɹ əm əweɪ. wɝmz əɹ blʌdʒɹæsps."

"That should be enough warning that something is wrong," Bashere said. "There are always patrols or raids of Trollocs to fight. If not that, then something worse, to scare them away. Worms or bloodwrasps."

ɪɾɝɑldi lind wʌn ɑɹm ɑn ɪz sæɾəl, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ əz i kəntɪnjud stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə blaɪt. "aɪv noʊ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð faɪɾɪŋ sətʃ θɪŋz. aɪ noʊ haʊ mɛn θɪŋk, bʌt tʃɹɑlɑk ɹeɪɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz kip noʊ səplaɪ laɪnz, ən aɪv oʊnli hɝd stɔɹiz ʌv wʌt wɝmz kən du."

Ituralde leaned one arm on his saddle, shaking his head as he continued staring at the Blight. "I've no experience with fighting such things. I know how men think, but Trolloc raiding parties keep no supply lines, and I've only heard stories of what worms can do."

"aɪ wɪl liv səm ə bæʃɪɹz ɔfəsɝz wɪð jə əz ædvaɪzɝz," ɹænd sɛd.

"I will leave some of Bashere's officers with you as advisors," Rand said.

"ðæt wəd hɛlp," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ɪt wʊdn bi bɛɾɝ tə dʒʌs liv ɪm hɪɹ. hɪz soʊlʒɝz kəd pətʃɹoʊl ðɪs ɛɹiə, ən jə kəd juz maɪ tʃɹups ɪn ɑɹæd dumən. noʊ əfɛns, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌt doʊn jə θɪŋk ɪts ɑd tə hæv əs wɝkɪŋ ɪn itʃ ʌðɝz kɪŋdəmz?"

"That would help," Ituralde said, "but I wonder if it wouldn't be better to just leave him here. His soldiers could patrol this area, and you could use my troops in Arad Doman. No offense, my Lord, but don't you think it's odd to have us working in each other's kingdoms?"

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛd. ɪt wɑzn ɑd, ɪt wɑz bɪɾɝ sɛns. hi tʃɹʌstɪd bæʃɪɹ, ən ðə sɑldəiənz hæd sɝvd ɹænd wɛl, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi deɪnʒɝəs tə liv əm ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn hoʊmlænz. bæʃɪɹ wɑz ʌŋkəl tə ðə kwin hɝsɛlf, ən wʌɾ ə hɪz mɛn? haʊ wəd ðeɪ ɹiækt wən ðɛɹ oʊn pipəl æskt waɪ ðeɪ hæd bɪkʌm dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn? stʃɹeɪnʒ əz ɪt wɑz, ɹænd nu ðəɾ i wəd kɑz ə mʌtʃ smɔlɝ kɑnfləɡɹeɪʃən baɪ livɪŋ fɔɹənɝz ɑn sɑldəiən sɔɪl.

"No," Rand said. It wasn't odd, it was bitter sense. He trusted Bashere, and the Saldaeans had served Rand well, but it would be dangerous to leave them in their own homelands. Bashere was uncle to the Queen herself, and what of his men? How would they react when their own people asked why they had become Dragonsworn? Strange as it was, Rand knew that he would cause a much smaller conflagration by leaving foreigners on Saldaean soil.

hɪz ɹizənɪŋ wɪð ɪɾɝɑldi wɑz ikwəli bɹuɾəl. ðə mæn hæd swɔɹn tə hɪm, bʌɾ ælidʒiænsɪz kəd tʃeɪnʒ. aʊt hɪɹ, nɪɹ ðə blaɪt, ɪɾɝɑldi ən ɪz tʃɹups wəɾ əv vɛɹi lɪɾəl ɑpɝtunəɾi tə tɝn əɡɛnst ɹænd. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn hɑstəl tɛɹɪtɔɹi, ən ɹændz æʃəmən wəd bi ðɛɹ oʊnli kwɪk minz ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk tə ɑɹæd dumən. ɪf lɛft ɪn ɪz hoʊmlænd, haʊɛvɝ, ɪɾɝɑldi kəd mɑɹʃəl tʃɹups ən pɝhæps dɪsaɪɾ i dɪdnt nid ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹnz pɹətɛkʃən.

His reasoning with Ituralde was equally brutal. The man had sworn to him, but allegiances could change. Out here, near the Blight, Ituralde and his troops would have very little opportunity to turn against Rand. They were in hostile territory, and Rand's Asha'man would be their only quick means of getting back to Arad Doman. If left in his homeland, however, Ituralde could marshal troops and perhaps decide he didn't need the Dragon Reborn's protection.

ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ seɪfɝ tə kip ði ɑɹmiz ɪn hɑstəl tɛɹɪtɔɹi. ɹænd heɪɾəd θɪŋkɪŋ ðət weɪ, bʌt ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə meɪn dɪfɝənsɪz bɪtwin ðə mæn i hæd bɪn ən ðə mæn i hæd bɪkʌm. oʊnli wʌn ə ðoʊz mɛn kəd də wʌt niɾəd tə bi dʌn, noʊ mæɾɝ ðəɾ i heɪɾəd ɪt.

It was much safer to keep the armies in hostile territory. Rand hated thinking that way, but that was one of the main differences between the man he had been and the man he had become. Only one of those men could do what needed to be done, no matter that he hated it.

"nɛɹɪʃmə," ɹænd kɔld. "ɡeɪtweɪ."

"Narishma," Rand called. "Gateway."

hi dɪdn əv tə tɝn tə fil nɛɹɪʃmə siz ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən bɪɡɪn wivɪŋ. ðə sɛnseɪʃən pɹɪkəld ət ɹænd, ɛntaɪsɪŋ, bʌɾ i fɔɾ ɪɾ ɔf. ɪt wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ dɪfəkəl fəɹ ɪm tə siz ðə paʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛmptiɪŋ ɪz stʌmək, ən i dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə sɪk ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪɾɝɑldi.

He didn't have to turn to feel Narishma seize the One Power and begin weaving. The sensation prickled at Rand, enticing, but he fought it off. It was becoming more and more difficult for him to seize the Power without emptying his stomach, and he did not intend to sick up in front of Ituralde.

"ju ʃæl əv ə hʌnʒɹəd æʃəmən baɪ ði ɛn ə ðə wik," ɹænd sɛd, spikɪŋ tə ɪɾɝɑldi. "aɪ səspɛk jəl meɪk ɡʊd jus ə ðɛm."

"You shall have a hundred Asha'man by the end of the week," Rand said, speaking to Ituralde. "I suspect you will make good use of them."

"jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən də dʒʌs ðæt."

"Yes, I think I can do just that."

"aɪ wɑn deɪli ɹɪpɔɹts, ivən ɪf nʌθɪŋ hæpənz," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd. "sɛn ðə mɛsənʒɝz θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ. əl bi bɹeɪkɪŋ kæmp ən muvɪŋ tə bændɑɹ ɛbən ɪn fɔɹ deɪz."

"I want daily reports, even if nothing happens," Rand replied. "Send the messengers through a gateway. I'll be breaking camp and moving to Bandar Eban in four days."

bæʃɪɹ ɡɹʌntɪd; ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝst ɹænd hæd sɛɾ ə ðə muv. ɹænd tɝn ɪz hɔɹs təwɔɹd ðə lɑɹdʒ, oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. səm ə ðə meɪɾənz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dʌk θɹu, ɡoʊɪŋ fɝst, əz ɔlweɪz. nɛɹɪʃmə stʊd tə ðə saɪd, hɪz hɛɹ ɪn ɪts tu dɑɹk bɹeɪdz sɛt wɪð bɛlz. hi hæd bɪn ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ, tu, bɪfɔɹ i hæd bɪkʌm æʃəmən. tu mɛni klaʊɾəd lɔɪəltiz. wɪtʃ wəd kʌm fɝs fəɹ nɛɹɪʃmə? hɪz hoʊmlænd? ɹænd? ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hum i wɑz ə wɔɹɾɝ? ɹænd wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən ðə mæn wɑz lɔɪəl; hi wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæd kʌm tə hɪm ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. bʌt ðə moʊs deɪnʒɝəs ɛnəmiz wɝ ðoʊz jə əsum jə kəd tʃɹʌst.

Bashere grunted; this was the first Rand had said of the move. Rand turned his horse toward the large, open gateway behind them. Some of the Maidens had already ducked through, going first, as always. Narishma stood to the side, his hair in its two dark braids set with bells. He had been a Borderlander, too, before he had become Asha'man. Too many clouded loyalties. Which would come first for Narishma? His homeland? Rand? The Aes Sedai to whom he was a Warder? Rand was fairly certain the man was loyal; he was one of those who had come to him at Dumai's Wells. But the most dangerous enemies were those you assumed you could trust.

nʌn ə ðɛm kən bi tʃɹʌstɪd! luz θɝɪn sɛd. wi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛɾ əm ɡɛt soʊ kloʊs tə ʌs. ðəl tɝn ɑn ʌs!

None of them can be trusted! Lews Therin said. We should never have let them get so close to us. They'll turn on us!

ðə mædmæn ɔlweɪz hæd tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ʌðɝ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. ɹænd nʌdʒ teɪdeɪʃɝ fɔɹwɝd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ luz θɝɪnz ɹæmbəlɪŋz, ðoʊ hɪɹɪŋ ðə vɔɪs dɪd teɪk ɪm bæk tə ðət naɪt.

The madman always had trouble with other men who could channel. Rand nudged Tai'daishar forward, ignoring Lews Therin's ramblings, though hearing the voice did take him back to that night.

ðə naɪt wɛɹ i hæd dʒɹimd ə mɔɹaɪɾɪn, ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ luz θɝɪn ɪn ɪz maɪnd. ɪt twɪstəd ɹændz bɛli tə noʊ ðəɾ ɪz dʒɹimz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ seɪf. hi hæd kʌm tə ɹɪlaɪ ɑn əm əz ə ɹɛfjudʒ. naɪtmɛɹz kəd teɪk hɪm, tʃɹu, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɪz oʊn naɪtmɛɹz.

The night where he had dreamed of Moridin, and there had been no Lews Therin in his mind. It twisted Rand's belly to know that his dreams were no longer safe. He had come to rely on them as a refuge. Nightmares could take him, true, but they were his own nightmares.

waɪ hæd mɔɹaɪɾɪn kʌm tə hɛlp ɹænd ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, bæk dʊɹɪŋ ðə faɪt wɪð sɑmaɪl? wʌt twɪstəd wɛbz wɑz i wivɪŋ? hi hæd kleɪm ðət ɹænd hæɾ ɪnveɪɾəd ɪz dʒɹim, bʌt wɑz ðət dʒʌst ənʌðɝ laɪ?

Why had Moridin come to help Rand in Shadar Logoth, back during the fight with Sammael? What twisted webs was he weaving? He had claimed that Rand had invaded his dream, but was that just another lie?

aɪ hæv tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm, hi θɔt. ɔl ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ən aɪ mʌs də ɪt fəɹ ɡʊd ðɪs taɪm. aɪ mʌs bi hɑɹd.

I have to destroy them, he thought. All of the Forsaken, and I must do it for good this time. I must be hard.

ɪksɛp ðət mɪn dɪdnt wɑn ɪm tə bi hɑɹd. hi dɪdnt wɑnə fɹaɪɾən hɝ, ʌv ɔl pipəl. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɡeɪmz wɪð mɪn; ʃi maɪt kɔl ɪm ə ful, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪ, ən ðət meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə bi ðə mæn ʃi wɪʃt ɪm tə bi. bʌt dɪɾ i dɛɹ? kəɾ ə mæn u kəd læf ɔlsoʊ bi ðə mæn u kəd feɪs wʌt niɾəd tə bi dʌn ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl?

Except that Min didn't want him to be hard. He didn't want to frighten her, of all people. There were no games with Min; she might call him a fool, but she did not lie, and that made him want to be the man she wished him to be. But did he dare? Could a man who could laugh also be the man who could face what needed to be done at Shayol Ghul?

tə lɪv jə mʌs daɪ, ði ænsɝ tə wʌn ə hɪz θɹi kwɛstʃənz. ɪf i səksiɾəd, hɪz mɛmɹi - hɪz lɛɡəsi - wəd lɪv ɑn æftɝ i daɪd. ɪt wɑz nɑt vɛɹi kʌmfɝɾɪŋ. hi dɪdnt wɑnə daɪ. hu dɪd? ði il kleɪm ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sik dɛθ, ðoʊ ðeɪ ɛmbɹeɪst ɪt wən ɪt keɪm.

To live you must die, the answer to one of his three questions. If he succeeded, his memory - his legacy - would live on after he died. It was not very comforting. He didn't want to die. Who did? The Aiel claimed they did not seek death, though they embraced it when it came.

hi ɛntɝd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, tʃɹævlɪŋ bæk tə ðə mænɝ haʊs ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, wɪð ðə ɹɪŋ ə paɪnz sɝaʊndɪŋ ðə tʃɹæmpəl bɹaʊn ɡɹaʊnz ən ðə lɔŋ ɹæŋks ə tɛns. ɪt wəd teɪk ə hɑɹd mæn tə feɪs ɪz oʊn dɛθ, tə faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn waɪl ɪz blʌd spɪld ɑn ðə ɹɑks. hu kəd læf ɪn ðə feɪs ə ðæt?

He entered the gateway, Traveling back to the manor house in Arad Doman, with the ring of pines surrounding the trampled brown grounds and the long ranks of tents. It would take a hard man to face his own death, to fight the Dark One while his blood spilled on the rocks. Who could laugh in the face of that?

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hævɪŋ luz θɝɪn ɪn ɪz maɪn dɪdn hɛlp.

He shook his head. Having Lews Therin in his mind didn't help.

ʃiz ɹaɪt, luz θɝɪn sɛd sʌɾənli.

She's right, Lews Therin said suddenly.

ʃi? ɹænd æskt.

She? Rand asked.

ðə pɹɪɾi wʌn. wɪð ðə ʃɔɹt hɛɹ. ʃi sɛz wi nid tə bɹeɪk ðə silz. ʃiz ɹaɪt.

The pretty one. With the short hair. She says we need to break the seals. She's right.

ɹænd fɹoʊz, pʊlɪŋ teɪdeɪʃɝ ʌp ʃɔɹt, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə ɡɹum u hæd kʌm tə teɪk ðə hɔɹs. tə hɪɹ luz θɝɪn əɡɹiɪŋ. . . .

Rand froze, pulling Tai'daishar up short, ignoring the groom who had come to take the horse. To hear Lews Therin agreeing. . . .

wʌt də wi də æftɝ ðæt? ɹænd æskt.

What do we do after that? Rand asked.

wi daɪ. jə pɹɑməst wi kəd daɪ!

We die. You promised we could die!

oʊnli ɪf wi dɪfit ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɹænd sɛd. jə noʊ ðəɾ ɪf i wɪnz, ðəɹ wɪl bi nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ʌs. nɑɾ ivən dɛθ.

Only if we defeat the Dark One, Rand said. You know that if he wins, there will be nothing for us. Not even death.

jɛs . . . nʌθɪŋ, luz θɝɪn sɛd. ðət wəd bi naɪs. noʊ peɪn, noʊ ɹəɡɹɛt. nʌθɪŋ.

Yes . . . nothing, Lews Therin said. That would be nice. No pain, no regret. Nothing.

ɹænd fɛlt ə tʃɪl. ɪf luz θɝɪn bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðət weɪ . . . noʊ, ɹænd sɛd, ɪt wʊdn bi nʌθɪŋ. hi wəɾ əv əɹ soʊl. ðə peɪn wəd bi wɝs, fɑɹ wɝs.

Rand felt a chill. If Lews Therin began to think that way . . . No, Rand said, it wouldn't be nothing. He would have our soul. The pain would be worse, far worse.

luz θɝɪn bɪɡæn tə wip.

Lews Therin began to weep.

luz θɝɪn! ɹænd snæpt ɪn ɪz maɪnd. wʌt də wi du? haʊ dɪd jə sil ðə bɔɹ læs taɪm?

Lews Therin! Rand snapped in his mind. What do we do? How did you seal the Bore last time?

ɪt dɪdnt wɝk, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. wi juz seɪɾɪn, bʌt wi tʌtʃt ɪt tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ! sʌmθɪŋ əz tə tʌtʃ hɪm, sʌmθɪŋ tə kloʊz ðə ɡæp, bʌɾ i wɑz eɪbəl tə teɪn ɪt. ðə sil wɑz wik!

It didn't work, Lews Therin whispered. We used saidin, but we touched it to the Dark One. It was the only way! Something has to touch him, something to close the gap, but he was able to taint it. The seal was weak!

jɛs, bʌt wʌt də wi də dɪfɹənli? ɹænd θɔt.

Yes, but what do we do differently? Rand thought.

saɪləns. ɹænd sæt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən slɪɾ ɔf ə teɪdeɪʃɝ ən lɛt ðə nɝvəs ɡɹum lɛɾ ɪm əweɪ. ðə ɹɛst ə ðə meɪɾənz wɝ kʌmɪŋ θɹu ðə lɑɹdʒ ɡeɪtweɪ, bæʃɪɹ ən nɛɹɪʃmə teɪkɪŋ ðə ɹɪɹ. ɹænd dɪdnt weɪt fəɹ ðɛm, ðoʊ hi noʊɾəst dʒɹə bæʃɪɹ - dævɹæm bæʃɪɹz waɪf -  stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd. ðə tɔl, stætʃuɛsk wʊmən hæd dɑɹk hɛɹ wɪð laɪnz ʌv waɪɾ ət ðə tɛmpəlz. ʃi ɡeɪv ɹænd ə mɛʒɝɪŋ lʊk. wʌt wəd ʃi də ɪf bæʃɪɹ daɪɾ ɪn ɹændz sɝvəs?

Silence. Rand sat for a moment, then slid off of Tai'daishar and let the nervous groom lead him away. The rest of the Maidens were coming through the large gateway, Bashere and Narishma taking the rear. Rand didn't wait for them, though he noticed Deira Bashere - Davram Bashere's wife -  standing outside the Traveling ground. The tall, statuesque woman had dark hair with lines of white at the temples. She gave Rand a measuring look. What would she do if Bashere died in Rand's service?

wəd ʃi kəntɪnju tə fɑloʊ, əɹ wəd ʃi lɛd ðə tʃɹups əweɪ, bæk tə sɑldɑiə? ʃi wɑz əz stʃɹɔŋ ʌv wɪl əz əɹ hʌzbənd. pɝhæps mɔɹ soʊ.

Would she continue to follow, or would she lead the troops away, back to Saldaea? She was as strong of will as her husband. Perhaps more so.

ɹænd pæst əɹ wɪð ə nɑɾ ən ə smaɪl ən wɔk θɹu ði ivnɪŋ kæmp təwɔɹd ðə mænɝ haʊs. soʊ luz θɝɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə sil ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. wʌt ɡʊd wɑz ðə vɔɪs ðɛn? bɝn hɪm, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn wʌn ə ɹændz fju hoʊps!

Rand passed her with a nod and a smile and walked through the evening camp toward the manor house. So Lews Therin did not know how to seal the Dark One's prison. What good was the voice then? Burn him, but he had been one of Rand's few hopes!

moʊs pipəl hɪɹ wɝ waɪz ɪnʌf tə muv əweɪ wən ðeɪ sɔ hɪm stɔkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnz. ɹænd kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən sətʃ mudz hædn stʃɹʌk hɪm, wən i hæd bɪn ə sɪmpəl ʃifɝɾɝ. ɹænd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ə dɪfɹən mæn ɔltəɡɛðɝ. hi wɑz ə mæn ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ən duɾi. hi hæd tə bi.

Most people here were wise enough to move away when they saw him stalking across the grounds. Rand could remember when such moods hadn't struck him, when he had been a simple sheepherder. Rand the Dragon Reborn was a different man altogether. He was a man of responsibility and duty. He had to be.

duɾi. duɾi wɑz laɪk ə maʊntən. wɛl, ɹænd fɛlt əz ɪf i wɑz tʃɹæp bɪtwin ə ɡʊd dʌzən dɪfɹən maʊntənz, ɔl muvɪŋ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm. əmʌŋ ðoʊz fɔɹsɪz, hɪz ɪmoʊʃənz sim tə bɔɪl ʌndɝ pɹɛʃɝ. wɑz ɪɾ ɛni wʌndɝ wən ðeɪ bɝs fɹi?

Duty. Duty was like a mountain. Well, Rand felt as if he was trapped between a good dozen different mountains, all moving to destroy him. Among those forces, his emotions seemed to boil under pressure. Was it any wonder when they burst free?

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə mænɝ. tə ði is leɪ ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. ðə sʌn wɑz nɪɹ tə sɛɾɪŋ, ən ðə maʊntənz wɝ beɪðd ɪn ə ɹɛd laɪt. bɪɑn əm ən tə ðə saʊθ, soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒli kloʊs, leɪ ɛmənz fild ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ə hoʊm i wəd nɛvɝ si əɡɛn, fəɹ ə vɪzət wəɾ oʊnli əlɝɾ ɪz ɛnəmiz tə hɪz əfɛkʃən fəɹ ɪt. hi hæd wɝk hɑɹd tə meɪk əm θɪŋk i wɑz ə mæn wɪθaʊɾ əfɛkʃən. ət taɪmz, hi fɪɹd ðəɾ ɪz ɹuz hæd bɪkʌm ɹiæləɾi.

He shook his head, approaching the manor. To the east lay the Mountains of Mist. The sun was near to setting, and the mountains were bathed in a red light. Beyond them and to the south, so strangely close, lay Emond's Field and the Two Rivers. A home he would never see again, for a visit would only alert his enemies to his affection for it. He had worked hard to make them think he was a man without affection. At times, he feared that his ruse had become reality.

maʊntənz. maʊntənz laɪk duɾi. ðə duɾi ʌv sɑlətuɾ ɪn ðɪs keɪs, fəɹ sʌmwɛɹ saʊθwɝɾ əlɔŋ ðoʊz tu-nɪɹ maʊntənz wɑz ɪz fɑðɝ. tæm. ɹænd hædn sin ɪm ɪn soʊ lɔŋ. tæm wɑz ɪz fɑðɝ.

Mountains. Mountains like duty. The duty of solitude in this case, for somewhere southward along those too-near mountains was his father. Tam. Rand hadn't seen him in so long. Tam was his father.

ɹænd hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðæt. hi hæd nɛvɝ noʊn ɪz bɝθ fɑðɝ, ði il klæn tʃif neɪm dʒɑnduən, ən waɪl i hæɾ ɑbviəsli bɪn ə mæn ʌv ɑnɝ, ɹænd hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə kɔl ɪm fɑðɝ.

Rand had decided that. He had never known his birth father, the Aiel clan chief named Janduin, and while he had obviously been a man of honor, Rand had no desire to call him father.

ət taɪmz, ɹænd lɔŋ fəɹ tæmz vɔɪs, hɪz wɪzdəm. ðoʊz wɝ ðə taɪmz wən ɹænd nu hi hæd tə bi ðə moʊs hɑɹd, fəɹ ə moʊmən ʌv wiknəs - ə moʊmən ɹʌnɪŋ tə hɪz fɑðɝ fəɹ sʌkɝ -  wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ nɪɹli ɛvɹiθɪŋ i hæd wɝk fɔɹ. ən ɪt wəd laɪkli min ði ɛn ə tæmz laɪf əz wɛl.

At times, Rand longed for Tam's voice, his wisdom. Those were the times when Rand knew he had to be the most hard, for a moment of weakness - a moment running to his father for succor -  would destroy nearly everything he had worked for. And it would likely mean the end of Tam's life as well.

ɹænd ɛntɝd ðə mænɝ haʊs θɹu ðə bɝn hoʊl ɪn ðə fɹʌnt, pʊʃɪŋ əsaɪd ðə θɪk kænvəs ðət naʊ fɔɹmd ən ɛntʃɹi, ən kɛpt ɪz bæk tə ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. hi wɑz əloʊn. hi niɾəd tə bi əloʊn. ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn ɛniwʌn wəd ɹɪsk biɪŋ wik wən i ɹitʃt ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ət ðə læs bæɾəl, hi wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə lin ɑn ɛniwʌn ʌðɝ ðən hɪmsɛlf.

Rand entered the manor house through the burned hole in the front, pushing aside the thick canvas that now formed an entry, and kept his back to the Mountains of Mist. He was alone. He needed to be alone. Relying on anyone would risk being weak when he reached Shayol Ghul. At the Last Battle, he would not be able to lean on anyone other than himself.

duɾi. haʊ mɛni maʊntənz mʌst wʌn mæn kæɹi?

Duty. How many mountains must one man carry?

ɪt stɪl smɛld ə smoʊk ɪnsaɪd ðə mænɝ haʊs. lɔɹd tɛleɪən hæd kəmpleɪn əbaʊt ðə faɪɝ hɛzɪɾəntli - jɛt pɝsɪstənli - əntɪl ɹænd hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd kɑmpənseɪʃən fəɹ ðə mæn, ɔlðoʊ ðə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl hædn bɪn ɹændz fɔlt. əɹ hæɾ ɪt? biɪŋ tɑvɝən hæd mɛni stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪfɛks, fɹəm meɪkɪŋ pipəl seɪ θɪŋz ðeɪ wʊdnt nɔɹməli tə bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪm ði əlidʒəns ə ðoʊz u hæd bɪn weɪvɝɪŋ. hi wɑz ə foʊkəs fəɹ tʃɹʌbəl, bʌbəlz ʌv ivəl ɪnkluɾəd. hi hædn tʃoʊzən tə bi ðət foʊkəs, bʌɾ i hæd tʃoʊzən tə steɪ ɪn ðə mænɝ haʊs.

It still smelled of smoke inside the manor house. Lord Tellaen had complained about the fire hesitantly - yet persistently - until Rand had ordered compensation for the man, although the bubble of evil hadn't been Rand's fault. Or had it? Being ta'veren had many strange effects, from making people say things they wouldn't normally to bringing him the allegiance of those who had been wavering. He was a focus for trouble, bubbles of evil included. He hadn't chosen to be that focus, but he had chosen to stay in the manor house.

iðɝ weɪ, tɛleɪən hæd bɪn kɑmpənseɪɾəd. ɪt wɑz ə pɪɾəns kəmpɛɹd wɪð ði əmaʊn ə mʌni ɹænd wɑz spɛndɪŋ tə fʌn ɪz ɑɹmiz, ən ivən ðət wɑz smɔl kəmpɛɹd wɪð ðə fʌnz hid dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə bɹɪŋ fud tə ɑɹæd dumən ən ʌðɝ tʃɹʌbəld ɛɹiəz. ət ðɪs ɹeɪt, hɪz stuɝdz wɝid ðəɾ i wəd sun bæŋkɹəpt ɪz æsɛts ɪn ɪljən, tiɹ ən kɛɹhin. ɹænd hæd nɑt toʊld əm ðəɾ i dɪdn kɛɹ.

Either way, Tellaen had been compensated. It was a pittance compared with the amount of money Rand was spending to fund his armies, and even that was small compared with the funds he'd dedicated to bring food to Arad Doman and other troubled areas. At this rate, his stewards worried that he would soon bankrupt his assets in Illian, Tear and Cairhien. Rand had not told them that he didn't care.

hi wəd si ðə wɝl tə ðə læs bæɾəl.

He would see the world to the Last Battle.

ən wɪl juv noʊ lɛɡəsi ʌðɝ ðən ðæt? ə vɔɪs wɪspɝɾ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. nɑt luz θɝɪn, bʌɾ ɪz oʊn θɔt, ə smɔl vɔɪs, ðə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm ðət hæd pɹɑmptəɾ ɪm tə faʊn skulz ɪn kɛɹhin ən ændɝ. jə wɪʃ tə lɪv æftɝ jə daɪ? wɪl jə liv ɔl ə ðoʊz u fɑloʊ jə tə wɔɹ, fæmən ən keɪɑs? wɪl ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən bi haʊ jə lɪv ɑn?

And will you have no legacy other than that? a voice whispered in the back of his mind. Not Lews Therin, but his own thought, a small voice, the part of him that had prompted him to found schools in Cairhien and Andor. You wish to live after you die? Will you leave all of those who follow you to war, famine and chaos? Will the destruction be how you live on?

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi kʊdn fɪks ɛvɹiθɪŋ! hi wɑz dʒʌst wʌn mæn. lʊkɪŋ bɪɑn ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz fulɪʃ. hi kʊdnt wɝi əbaʊt ðə wɝl ðɛn, hi kʊdnt. tə də soʊ wəd bi tə teɪk ɪz aɪ ɔf ðə ɡoʊl.

Rand shook his head. He couldn't fix everything! He was just one man. Looking beyond the Last Battle was foolish. He couldn't worry about the world then, he couldn't. To do so would be to take his eye off the goal.

ən wʌɾ ɪz ðə ɡoʊl? ðət vɔɪs sim tə seɪ. ɪz ɪt tə sɝvaɪv, əɹ ɪz ɪt tə θɹaɪv? wɪl jə sɛt ðə ɡɹaʊndwɝk fəɹ ənʌðɝ bɹeɪkɪŋ əɹ fəɹ ənʌðɝ eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz?

And what is the goal? that voice seemed to say. Is it to survive, or is it to thrive? Will you set the groundwork for another Breaking or for another Age of Legends?

hi hæd noʊ ænsɝz. luz θɝɪn ɹaʊz slaɪtli, bæbəlɪŋ ɪnkoʊhɪɹənli. ɹænd klaɪm ðə stɛɹz tə ðə sɛkən flɔɹ ə ðə mænɝ. laɪt, hi wɑz taɪɝd.

He had no answers. Lews Therin roused slightly, babbling incoherently. Rand climbed the stairs to the second floor of the manor. Light, he was tired.

wʌt wɑz ɪt ðə mædmæn hæd sɛd? wən hid sil ðə bɔɹ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, hid juz seɪɾɪn. ðət wɑz kəz soʊ mɛni ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ət ðə taɪm hæd tɝn əɡɛns hɪm, ən hid bɪn lɛft oʊnli wɪð ðə hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz - ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ɪz taɪm. noʊ wɪmən. ðə fimeɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd kɔld ɪz plæn tu ɹɪski.

What was it the madman had said? When he'd sealed the Bore into the Dark One's prison, he'd used saidin. That was because so many of the Aes Sedai at the time had turned against him, and he'd been left only with the Hundred Companions - the most powerful male Aes Sedai of his time. No women. The female Aes Sedai had called his plan too risky.

ɪɹəli, ɹænd fɛlt əz ɪf i kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðoʊz ɪvɛns - nɑt wʌt hæd hæpənd, bʌt ði æŋɡɝ, ðə dɛspɝeɪʃən, ðə dɪsɪʒən. wɑz ðə mɪsteɪk, ðɛn, nɑt juzɪŋ ðə fimeɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ əz wɛl əz ðə meɪl? wɑz ðət wʌt hæɾ əlaʊd ðə dɑɹk wʌn tə kaʊntɝstʃɹaɪk ən teɪn seɪɾɪn, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ luz θɝɪn ən ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ mɛn ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz ɪnseɪn?

Eerily, Rand felt as if he could almost remember those events - not what had happened, but the anger, the desperation, the decision. Was the mistake, then, not using the female half of the power as well as the male? Was that what had allowed the Dark One to counterstrike and taint saidin, driving Lews Therin and the remaining men of the Hundred Companions insane?

kəɾ ɪt bi ðət sɪmpəl? haʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ i nid? wəɾ i niɾ ɛni? plɛnti ʌv waɪz wʌnz kəd tʃænəl. ʃʊɹli ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən ðæt.

Could it be that simple? How many Aes Sedai would he need? Would he need any? Plenty of Wise Ones could channel. Surely there was more to it than that.

ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡeɪm tʃɪlʒɹən pleɪd, sneɪks ən fɑksəz. ɪt wɑz sɛd ðət ði oʊnli weɪ tə wɪn wɑz tə bɹeɪk ðə ɹulz. wʌɾ ə hɪz ʌðɝ plæn, ðɛn? kəɾ i bɹeɪk ðə ɹulz baɪ sleɪɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn? wɑz ðət sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ivən hi, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, dɛɹd kɑntəmpleɪt?

There was a game children played, Snakes and Foxes. It was said that the only way to win was to break the rules. What of his other plan, then? Could he break the rules by slaying the Dark One? Was that something that even he, the Dragon Reborn, dared contemplate?

hi kɹɔs ðə kɹikɪŋ wʊd flɔɹ ə ðə hɔlweɪ ən pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə hɪz ɹum. mɪn leɪ pɹɑpt ʌp baɪ pɪloʊz ɑn ðə lɔɡ bɛd, wɛɹɪŋ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɡɹin tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə lɪnən ʃɝt, əz ʃi lif θɹu jɛɾ ənʌðɝ bʊk baɪ ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə læmp. ən ɛldɝli sɝvɪŋ wʊmən bʌsəld əbaʊt, kəlɛktɪŋ dɪʃəz fɹəm mɪnz ivnɪŋ mil. ɹænd θɹu ɔf ɪz koʊt, saɪɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf ən flɛksɪŋ ɪz hænd.

He crossed the creaking wood floor of the hallway and pushed open the door to his room. Min lay propped up by pillows on the log bed, wearing her embroidered green trousers and a linen shirt, as she leafed through yet another book by the light of a lamp. An elderly serving woman bustled about, collecting dishes from Min's evening meal. Rand threw off his coat, sighing to himself and flexing his hand.

hi sæt daʊn ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɛɾ əz mɪn sɛɾ əsaɪɾ əɹ bʊk, ə vɑljum kɔld eɪ kɑmpɹihɛnsɪv dɪskʌʃən ə pɹi-bɹeɪkɪŋ ɹɛlɪks. ʃi sæɾ ʌp ən ɹʌb ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk wɪð wʌn hænd. boʊlz klɪŋkt əz ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən ɡæðɝd ðɛm, ən ʃi baʊɾ ɪn əpɑlədʒi, muvɪŋ wɪð ɛkstʃɹə spiɾ əz ʃi pleɪst əm ɪn əɹ kæɹiɪŋ bæskət.

He sat down on the side of the bed as Min set aside her book, a volume called A Comprehensive Discussion of Pre-Breaking Relics. She sat up and rubbed the back of his neck with one hand. Bowls clinked as the serving woman gathered them, and she bowed in apology, moving with extra speed as she placed them in her carrying basket.

"jɔɹ pʊʃɪŋ jɝsɛlf tu hɑɹɾ əɡɛn, ʃifɝɾɝ," mɪn sɛd.

"You're pushing yourself too hard again, sheepherder," Min said.

"aɪ hæv tə."

"I have to."

ʃi pɪntʃt ɪz nɛk hɑɹd, ən i flɪntʃt, ɡɹʌntɪŋ. "noʊ jə doʊnt," ʃi sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs kloʊs tə hɪz ɪɹ. "hævən jə bɪn lɪsnɪŋ tə mi? wʌt ɡʊd wɪl jə bi ɪf jə wɛɹ jɝsɛlf aʊt bɪfɔɹ jə ɹitʃ ðə læs bæɾəl? laɪt, ɹænd, aɪ hævən hɝd jə læf ɪn mʌnθs!"

She pinched his neck hard, and he flinched, grunting. "No you don't," she said, her voice close to his ear. "Haven't you been listening to me? What good will you be if you wear yourself out before you reach the Last Battle? Light, Rand, I haven't heard you laugh in months!"

"ɪz ðɪs ɹɪli ə taɪm fəɹ læftɝ?" hi æskt. "ju wəɾ əv mi bi hæpi waɪl tʃɪlʒɹən stɑɹv ən mɛn slɔɾɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ? aɪ ʃəd læf tə hɪɹ ðət tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ stɪl ɡɛɾɪŋ θɹu ðə weɪz?

"Is this really a time for laughter?" he asked. "You would have me be happy while children starve and men slaughter one another? I should laugh to hear that Trollocs are still getting through the Ways?

aɪ ʃəd bi hæpi ðət ðə mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ stɪl aʊt ðəɹ sʌmwɛɹ, plɑɾɪŋ haʊ bɛs tə kɪl mi?"

I should be happy that the majority of the Forsaken are still out there somewhere, plotting how best to kill me?"

"wɛl, noʊ," mɪn sɛd. "ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. bʌt wi kæn lɛt ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ɪn ðə wɝl dɪstʃɹɔɪ ʌs.

"Well, no," Min said. "Of course not. But we can't let the troubles in the world destroy us.

kædzueɪn sɛz ðət - "

Cadsuane says that - "

"weɪt," hi snæpt, twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊn soʊ ðəɾ i wɑz feɪsɪŋ hɝ. ʃi nɛlt ɑn ðə bɛd, ʃɔɹt dɑɹk hɛɹ kɝlɪŋ daʊn bɪniθ əɹ tʃɪn. ʃi lʊkt ʃɑk baɪ hɪz toʊn.

"Wait," he snapped, twisting around so that he was facing her. She knelt on the bed, short dark hair curling down beneath her chin. She looked shocked by his tone.

"wʌt dʌz kædzueɪn əv tə də wɪð ðɪs?" hi æskt.

"What does Cadsuane have to do with this?" he asked.

mɪn fɹaʊnd. "nʌθɪŋ."

Min frowned. "Nothing."

"ʃiz bɪn tɛlɪŋ jə wʌt tə seɪ," ɹænd sɛd. "ʃiz bɪn juzɪŋ jə tə ɡɛt tə mi!"

"She's been telling you what to say," Rand said. "She's been using you to get to me!"

"doʊn bi ən ɪɾiət," mɪn sɛd.

"Don't be an idiot," Min said.

"wʌɾ əz ʃi sɛɾ əbaʊt mi?"

"What has she said about me?"

mɪn ʃɹʌɡd. "ʃi wɝiz əbaʊt haʊ hɑɹʃ juv bɪkʌm. ɹænd, wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?"

Min shrugged. "She worries about how harsh you've become. Rand, what is this?"

"ʃiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt tə mi, mənɪpjəleɪt mi," hi sɛd. "ʃiz juzɪŋ ju. wʌɾ əv jə toʊl hɝ, mɪn?"

"She's trying to get to me, manipulate me," he said. "She's using you. What have you told her, Min?"

mɪn pɪntʃt ɪm əɡɛn ʃɑɹpli. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ðət toʊn, lubi. aɪ θɔt kædzueɪn wɑz jəɹ kaʊnsəlɝ. waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ nid tə wɑtʃ wʌɾ aɪ seɪ ɝaʊn hɝ?"

Min pinched him again sharply. "I don't like that tone, looby. I thought Cadsuane was your counselor. Why should I need to watch what I say around her?"

ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən kəntɪnjud tə klɪŋk dɪʃəz. waɪ kʊdnt ʃi dʒʌs liv! ðɪs wɑzn ðə kaɪndə dɪskʌʃən i wɑntəd tə hæv ɪn fɹʌn ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz.

The serving woman continued to clink dishes. Why couldn't she just leave! This wasn't the kind of discussion he wanted to have in front of strangers.

mɪn kʊdn bi wɝkɪŋ wɪð kædzueɪn, kəd ʃi? ɹænd dɪdn tʃɹʌs kædzueɪn baɪ ɛni mɛʒɝ.

Min couldn't be working with Cadsuane, could she? Rand didn't trust Cadsuane by any measure.

ɪf ʃid ɡɑɾən tə mɪn. . . .

If she'd gotten to Min. . . .

ɹænd fɛlt ɪz hɑɹt twɪst. hi wɑzn səspɪʃəs ə mɪn, wɑz hi? ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ðə wʌn i kəd lʊk tə fəɹ ɑnəsti, ðə wʌn u pleɪd noʊ ɡeɪmz wɪð hɪm. wʌt wəɾ i də ɪf i lɔs hɝ?

Rand felt his heart twist. He wasn't suspicious of Min, was he? She'd always been the one he could look to for honesty, the one who played no games with him. What would he do if he lost her?

bɝn mi! hi θɔt. ʃiz ɹaɪt. aɪv ɡɹoʊn tu hɑɹʃ. wʌt wɪl bɪkʌm ə mi ɪf aɪ bɪɡɪn tə ɡɹoʊ səspɪʃəs ə ðoʊz ðəɾ aɪ noʊ lʌv mi? əl bi noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən mæd luz θɝɪn.

Burn me! he thought. She's right. I've grown too harsh. What will become of me if I begin to grow suspicious of those that I know love me? I'll be no better than mad Lews Therin.

"mɪn," hi sɛd, sɔfənɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs. "meɪbi jəɹ ɹaɪt. pɝhæps aɪv ɡɔn tu fɑɹ."

"Min," he said, softening his voice. "Maybe you're right. Perhaps I've gone too far."

ʃi tɝn tə lʊk ət hɪm, ɹɪlæksɪŋ. ðən ʃi stɪfənd, aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ ɪn ʃɑk.

She turned to look at him, relaxing. Then she stiffened, eyes widening in shock.

sʌmθɪŋ koʊl klɪkt ɝaʊn ɹændz nɛk.

Something cold clicked around Rand's neck.

ɹænd ɪmiɾiətli ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn tə hɪz nɛk, spɪnɪŋ. ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən stʊd bɪhaɪn hɪm, bʌɾ əɹ fɔɹm wɑz ʃɪmɝɪŋ. ʃi vænɪʃt ən wɑz ɹipleɪs baɪ ə wʊmən wɪð dɑɹk skɪn ən blæk aɪz, hɝ ʃɑɹp feɪs tʃɹaɪʌmfənt. sɛmɝhɪdʒ.

Rand immediately raised his hand to his neck, spinning. The serving woman stood behind him, but her form was shimmering. She vanished and was replaced by a woman with dark skin and black eyes, her sharp face triumphant. Semirhage.

ɹændz hæn tʌtʃt mɛɾəl. tu-koʊl mɛɾəl ðət fɛlt laɪk aɪs, pɹɛst əɡɛnst ɪz skɪn. ɪn ə ɹeɪdʒ, hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl fɹi hɪz sɔɹd fɹəm ɪts blæk, dʒɹæɡən-peɪntəd ʃiθ, bʌt faʊn ðəɾ i kəd nɑt də soʊ.

Rand's hand touched metal. Too-cold metal that felt like ice, pressed against his skin. In a rage, he tried to pull free his sword from its black, dragon-painted sheath, but found that he could not do so.

hɪz lɛɡz stʃɹeɪn əz ɪf əɡɛnst səm ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl weɪt. hi skɹætʃt ət ðə kɑlɝ - hɪz fɪŋɡɝz kəd stɪl muv - bʌt ðə mɛɾəl sim tə bi ə sɪŋɡəl sɑləd pis.

His legs strained as if against some incredible weight. He scratched at the collar - his fingers could still move - but the metal seemed to be a single solid piece.

ət ðət moʊmənt, ɹænd fɛl tɛɹɝ. hi mɛt sɛmɝhɪdʒəz aɪz ɛniweɪ, ən ʃi smaɪl dipli. "aɪv bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ kwaɪɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm tə ɡɛɾ ə dɑməneɪʃən bæn ɑn ju, luz θɝɪn. ɑd, haʊ sɝkəmstænsəz əkɝ, ɪzənt - "

At that moment, Rand felt terror. He met Semirhage's eyes anyway, and she smiled deeply. "I've been waiting for quite a long time to get a Domination Band on you, Lews Therin. Odd, how circumstances occur, isn't - "

sʌmθɪŋ flæʃt ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən sɛmɝhɪdʒ bɛɹli hæd taɪm tə kɹaɪ aʊt bɪfɔɹ sʌmθɪŋ dɪflɛktɪd ðə bleɪd dʒʌs bɛɹli - ə wiv ʌv ɛɹ, ɹænd kəɾ oʊnli əsum, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt si wivz meɪd fɹəm seɪaɪdɑɹ. stɪl, mɪnz naɪf hæd lɛft ə ɡæʃ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə sɛmɝhɪdʒəz feɪs bɪfɔɹ pæsɪŋ baɪ ən bɛɹiɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɪn ðə wʊɾ ə ðə dɔɹ.

Something flashed in the air, and Semirhage barely had time to cry out before something deflected the blade just barely - a weave of Air, Rand could only assume, though he could not see weaves made from saidar. Still, Min's knife had left a gash on the side of Semirhage's face before passing by and burying itself in the wood of the door.

"ɡɑɹdz!" mɪn kɹaɪd. "meɪɾənz, tə ɑɹmz! ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɪz ɪn deɪnʒɝ!"

"Guards!" Min cried. "Maidens, to arms! The Car'a'carn is in danger!"

sɛmɝhɪdʒ kɝst, weɪvɪŋ ə hænd, ən mɪn kʌɾ ɔf. ɹænd twɪstəɾ æŋkʃəsli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ - ən feɪlɪŋ -  tə siz seɪɾɪn. sʌmθɪŋ blɑk hɪm. mɪn wɑz tɔst ɔf ðə bɛd baɪ wivz ʌv ɛɹ, hɝ maʊθ lɑkt ʃʌt. ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn tə hɝ, bʌɾ əɡɛn faʊn ðəɾ i kəd nɑt. hɪz lɛɡz sɪmpli ɹəfjuz tə muv.

Semirhage cursed, waving a hand, and Min cut off. Rand twisted anxiously, trying - and failing -  to seize saidin. Something blocked him. Min was tossed off the bed by weaves of Air, her mouth locked shut. Rand tried to run to her, but again found that he could not. His legs simply refused to move.

ət ðət moʊmənt, ðə dɔɹ tə hɪz ɹum oʊpənd. ənʌðɝ wʊmən ɛntɝd wɪð ə hɝid stɛp. ʃi ɡlænst aʊɾ ə ðə dɔɹweɪ, əz ɪf wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, ðən kloʊzd ɪt bɪhaɪn hɝ. ɛlzə. ɹænd fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ə hoʊp, bʌt ðən ðə smɔl wʊmən dʒɔɪn sɛmɝhɪdʒ, teɪkɪŋ ʌp ði ʌðɝ bɹeɪslət ðət kəntʃɹoʊl ði æɾəm ɝaʊn ɹændz nɛk. ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət ɹænd, hɝ aɪz ɹɛd, lʊkɪŋ deɪzd - əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ hæd hɪɾ əɹ saʊnli ɑn ðə hɛd. haʊɛvɝ, wən ʃi sɔ hɪm nilɪŋ, ʃi smaɪld. "æn soʊ jə faɪnəli kʌm tə jəɹ dɛstəni, ɹænd ælθɹ. jəl feɪs ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. ən jəl luz."

At that moment, the door to his room opened. Another woman entered with a hurried step. She glanced out of the doorway, as if watching for something, then closed it behind her. Elza. Rand felt a surge of hope, but then the small woman joined Semirhage, taking up the other bracelet that controlled the a'dam around Rand's neck. She looked up at Rand, her eyes red, looking dazed - as if something had hit her soundly on the head. However, when she saw him kneeling, she smiled. "And so you finally come to your destiny, Rand al'Thor. You will face the Great Lord. And you will lose."

ɛlzə. ɛlzə wɑz blæk, bɝn hɝ! ɹændz skɪn pɹɪkəld əz i fɛlt əɹ ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ mɪstʃɹəs. ðeɪ boʊθ kənfɹʌntəd hɪm, itʃ wʌn wɛɹɪŋ ə bɹeɪslət, ən sɛmɝhɪdʒ lʊk supɹiməli kɑnfəɾənt.

Elza. Elza was Black, burn her! Rand's skin prickled as he felt her embrace saidar, standing beside her mistress. They both confronted him, each one wearing a bracelet, and Semirhage looked supremely confident.

ɹænd ɡɹaʊld, tɝnɪŋ tə sɛmɝhɪdʒ. hi wəd nɑt bi tʃɹæp laɪk ðɪs!

Rand growled, turning to Semirhage. He would not be trapped like this!
