ðə fɔɹseɪkən tʌtʃt ðə bliɾɪŋ ɡæʃ ɑn əɹ tʃik, ðən tsk tə hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɔɹ ə dʒɹæb bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs. haʊ hæd ʃi ɪskeɪp kæptɪvəɾi? ən wɛɹ hæd ʃi ɡɑɾən ðɪs kɝs kɑlɝ? ɹænd hæd ɡɪvən ðət tə kædzueɪn fəɹ seɪfkipɪŋ. ʃi hæd vaʊd ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi seɪf!

The Forsaken touched the bleeding gash on her cheek, then tsked to herself. She wore a drab brown dress. How had she escaped captivity? And where had she gotten this cursed collar? Rand had given that to Cadsuane for safekeeping. She had vowed that it would be safe!

"noʊ ɡɑɹdz wɪl kʌm, luz θɝɪn," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛɾ æbsənli, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp əɹ bɹeɪsləɾəd hænd;

"No guards will come, Lews Therin," Semirhage said absently, holding up her braceleted hand;

ðə bɹeɪslət mætʃt ðə kɑlɝ ɑn ɪz nɛk. "aɪv wɔɹɾɪd ðə ɹum əɡɛns lɪsənɝz. jəl faɪn ðət jə kænɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz muv ənlɛs aɪ əlaʊ ɪt. juv tʃɹaɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, ən jə mʌst si haʊ fjuɾəl ɪɾ ɪz."

the bracelet matched the collar on his neck. "I've warded the room against listeners. You will find that you cannot so much as move unless I allow it. You've tried already, and you must see how futile it is."

dɛspɹɪt, ɹænd ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪɾɪn əɡɛn, bʌt faʊnd nʌθɪŋ. ɪn ɪz hɛd, luz θɝɪn bɪɡæn tə snɑɹl ən wip, ən ɹænd fɛlt ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i wəd dʒɔɪn ðə mæn. mɪn! hi hæd tə ɡɛt tə hɝ. hi hæd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf!

Desperate, Rand reached for saidin again, but found nothing. In his head, Lews Therin began to snarl and weep, and Rand felt almost as if he would join the man. Min! He had to get to her. He had to be strong enough!

hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf təwɔɹd sɛmɝhɪdʒ ən ɛlzə, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz əz ɪf i wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə muv sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz lɛɡz. hi wɑz tʃɹæpt ɪn ɪz oʊn hɛd, laɪk luz θɝɪn. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə kɝs, bʌt nʌθɪŋ keɪm aʊt bɪɑn ə kɹoʊk.

He forced himself toward Semirhage and Elza, but it was as if he were trying to move someone else's legs. He was trapped in his own head, like Lews Therin. He opened his mouth to curse, but nothing came out beyond a croak.

"jɛs," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛd, "ju kænɑt spik wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən iðɝ. ən aɪ wəd sədʒɛs ðət jə nɑt ɹitʃ fəɹ seɪɾɪn əɡɛn. jəl faɪn ði ɪkspɪɹiəns ənplɛzənt. wən aɪ tɛstəd ðə dɑməneɪʃən bæn bɪfɔɹ, aɪ faʊn ɪt tə bi ə fɑɹ mɔɹ ɛləɡən tul ðən ðoʊz sintʃæn æɾəm. ðɛɹ æɾəm əlaʊ səm smɔl mɛʒɝ ə fɹiɾəm, ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn nɔziə əz ən ɪnhɪbəɾɝ. ðə dɑməneɪʃən bæn dɪmænz fɑɹ mɔɹ oʊbiɾiəns. jəl ækt ɪɡzækli əz aɪ dɪzaɪɝ. fəɹ ɪnstəns. . . ."

"Yes," Semirhage said, "you cannot speak without permission either. And I would suggest that you not reach for saidin again. You will find the experience unpleasant. When I tested the Domination Band before, I found it to be a far more elegant tool than those Seanchan a'dam. Their a'dam allow some small measure of freedom, relying on nausea as an inhibitor. The Domination Band demands far more obedience. You will act exactly as I desire. For instance. . . ."

ɹænd stʊɾ ʌp ɔf ðə bɛd, hɪz lɛɡz muvɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪz wɪl. ðɛn, hɪz oʊn hænd wɪpt ʌp ən bɪɡæn tə skwiz ɪz θɹoʊt dʒʌst əbʌv ðə nɛk bænd. hi ɡæspt, stʌmbəlɪŋ. fɹæntɪk, hi ɹitʃt əɡɛn fəɹ seɪɾɪn.

Rand stood up off the bed, his legs moving against his will. Then, his own hand whipped up and began to squeeze his throat just above the neck band. He gasped, stumbling. Frantic, he reached again for saidin.

hi faʊn peɪn. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf hid ɹitʃt ɪndə ə bɝnɪŋ væɾ ʌv ɔɪl, ðən dʒɹɔn ðə faɪɝi lɪkwəɾ ɪndə hɪz oʊn veɪnz. hi skɹimd ɪn ʃɑk ən æɡəni, kəlæpsɪŋ tə ðə wʊɾən flɔɹ. ðə peɪn meɪɾ ɪm ɹɪð, hɪz vɪʒən ɡɹoʊɪŋ blæk.

He found pain. It was as if he'd reached into a burning vat of oil, then drawn the fiery liquid into his own veins. He screamed in shock and agony, collapsing to the wooden floor. The pain made him writhe, his vision growing black.

"ju si." sɛmɝhɪdʒəz vɔɪs saʊndəd dɪstənt. "ɑ, aɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən haʊ sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz."

"You see." Semirhage's voice sounded distant. "Ah, I had forgotten how satisfying that is."

ðə peɪn wɑz laɪk ə mɪljən æns bɝoʊɪŋ θɹu hɪz skɪn ən daʊn tə ðə boʊn. hi twɪstəd, mʌsəlz spæzəmɪŋ.

The pain was like a million ants burrowing through his skin and down to the bone. He twisted, muscles spasming.

wɝ ɪn ðə bɑks əɡɛn! luz θɝɪn kɹaɪd.

We're in the box again! Lews Therin cried.

ən sʌɾənli, hi wɑz. hi kəd si ɪt, ðə blæk kɑnfaɪnz, kɹʌʃɪŋ hɪm. hɪz bɑɾi sɔɹ fɹəm ɹɪpiɾɪd biɾɪŋz, hɪz maɪn fɹæntɪk tə ɹɪmeɪn seɪn. luz θɝɪn hæd bɪn ɪz oʊnli kəmpænjən. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə fɝs taɪmz ɹænd kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ kəmjunəkeɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə mædmæn; luz θɝɪn hæd stɑɹɾəd tə ɹɪspɑn tə hɪm oʊnli ʃɔɹtli bɪfɔɹ ðət deɪ.

And suddenly, he was. He could see it, the black confines, crushing him. His body sore from repeated beatings, his mind frantic to remain sane. Lews Therin had been his only companion. It was one of the first times Rand could remember communicating with the madman; Lews Therin had started to respond to him only shortly before that day.

ɹænd hædn bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə si luz θɝɪn əz pɑɹɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. ðə mæd pɑɹɾ ə hɪmsɛlf, ðə pɑɹt ðət kəd dil wɪð ðə tɔɹtʃɝ, ɪf oʊnli kəz ɪt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi soʊ tɔɹtʃɝd. mɔɹ peɪn ən sʌfɝɪŋ wɑz minɪŋləs. jə kəd nɑt fɪl ə kʌp ðət hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn tə oʊvɝfloʊ.

Rand hadn't been willing to see Lews Therin as part of himself. The mad part of himself, the part that could deal with the torture, if only because it was already so tortured. More pain and suffering was meaningless. You could not fill a cup that had already begun to overflow.

hi stɑp skɹimɪŋ. ðə peɪn wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ɪt meɪɾ ɪz aɪz wɔɾɝ, bʌt ðə skɹimz wəd nɑt kʌm. ɔl fɛl stɪl.

He stopped screaming. The pain was still there, it made his eyes water, but the screams would not come. All fell still.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ lʊk daʊn ət hɪm, fɹaʊnɪŋ, blʌd dʒɹɪpɪŋ fɹəm əɹ tʃɪn. ənʌðɝ weɪv ə peɪn wɑʃt əkɹɔs hɪm. huɛvɝ i wɑz.

Semirhage looked down at him, frowning, blood dripping from her chin. Another wave of pain washed across him. Whoever he was.

hi stɛɹɾ ʌp ət hɝ. saɪlənt.

He stared up at her. Silent.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" ʃi sɛd, kəmpɛlɪŋ hɪm. "spik."

"What are you doing?" she said, compelling him. "Speak."

"noʊ mɔɹ kən bi dʌn tə mi," hi wɪspɝd.

"No more can be done to me," he whispered.

ənʌðɝ weɪv ə peɪn. ɪt ʃɑk hɪm, ən sʌmθɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm wɪmpɝd, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv noʊ aʊtwɝd ɹiækʃən. nɑt kəz i hɛl ðə skɹimz ɪn, bʌt kəz i kʊdn fil ɛniθɪŋ. ðə bɑks, ðə tu wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd kɝʌptɪŋ ɪz oʊn blʌd, biɾɪŋz, hjumɪlieɪʃən, sɑɹoʊz ən ɪz oʊn suəsaɪd. kɪlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. hi kəd sʌɾənli ən stɑɹkli ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. æftɝ ɔl ə ðiz θɪŋz, wʌt mɔɹ kəd sɛmɝhɪdʒ də tə hɪm?

Another wave of pain. It shocked him, and something inside of him whimpered, but he gave no outward reaction. Not because he held the screams in, but because he couldn't feel anything. The box, the two wounds in his side corrupting his own blood, beatings, humiliation, sorrows and his own suicide. Killing himself. He could suddenly and starkly remember that. After all of these things, what more could Semirhage do to him?

"ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ɛlzə sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə sɛmɝhɪdʒ, aɪz stɪl simɪŋ feɪnli deɪz baɪ sʌmθɪŋ.

"Great Mistress," Elza said, turning to Semirhage, eyes still seeming faintly dazed by something.

"pɝhæps naʊ wi ʃəd - "

"Perhaps now we should - "

"kwaɪət, wɝm," sɛmɝhɪdʒ spæɾ ət hɝ, waɪpɪŋ ðə blʌd fɹəm əɹ tʃɪn. ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪt. "ðæts twaɪs naʊ ðoʊz naɪvz əv teɪstəd maɪ blʌd." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ðən tɝn ən smaɪld ət ɹænd.

"Quiet, worm," Semirhage spat at her, wiping the blood from her chin. She looked at it. "That's twice now those knives have tasted my blood." She shook her head, then turned and smiled at Rand.

"ju seɪ nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ kən bi dʌn tə ju? jə fɝɡɛt, luz θɝɪn, tə hum jə spik. peɪn ɪz maɪ spɛʃəlti, ən jə ɑɹ stɪl lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə bɔɪ. aɪv bɹoʊkən mɛn tɛn taɪmz əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ju. stænd."

"You say nothing more can be done to you? You forget, Lews Therin, to whom you speak. Pain is my specialty, and you are still little more than a boy. I've broken men ten times as strong as you. Stand."

hi dɪd. ðə peɪn hæd nɑt ɡɔn əweɪ. ʃi ɑbviəsli ɪntɛndəd tə kip juzɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛnst ɪm əntɪl ʃi ɡɑɾ ə ɹiækʃən.

He did. The pain had not gone away. She obviously intended to keep using it against him until she got a reaction.

hi tɝn ɝaʊnd, oʊbeɪɪŋ əɹ wɝdləs kəmænd, ən faʊn mɪn hæŋɪŋ əbʌv ðə flɔɹ, taɪd baɪ ɪnvɪzəbəl ɹoʊps ʌv ɛɹ. hɝ aɪz wɝ waɪld wɪð fɪɹ, hɝ ɑɹmz baʊn bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk, hɝ maʊθ blɑk baɪ ə woʊvən ɛɹ ɡæɡ.

He turned around, obeying her wordless command, and found Min hanging above the floor, tied by invisible ropes of Air. Her eyes were wild with fear, her arms bound behind her back, her mouth blocked by a woven Air gag.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ tʃʌkəld. "ðɛɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðəɾ aɪ kən du, jə seɪ?"

Semirhage chuckled. "There is nothing more that I can do, you say?"

ɹænd siz seɪɾɪn - nɑɾ ə hɪz tʃɔɪs, bʌɾ ə hɝz. ðə ɹɔɹ ə paʊɝ slæmd ɪndə hɪm, bɹɪŋɪŋ wɪð ɪt ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ nɔziə ðət hid nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə ɪkspleɪn. hi fɛl tə hɪz hæn ən niz, ɛmptiɪŋ ɪz stʌmək wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn əz ðə ɹum ʃʊk ən spʌn ɝaʊn hɪm.

Rand seized saidin - not of his choice, but of hers. The roar of power slammed into him, bringing with it the strange nausea that he'd never been able to explain. He fell to his hand and knees, emptying his stomach with a groan as the room shook and spun around him.

"haʊ ɑd," hi hɝd sɛmɝhɪdʒ seɪ, əz ɪf dɪstənt. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ  - ɹɛslɪŋ wɪð ɪɾ əz i ɔlweɪz hæd tə wɪð seɪɾɪn, fɔɹsɪŋ ðət paʊɝfəl, twɪstɪŋ floʊ ʌv ɛnɝdʒi tə hɪz wɪl. ɪt wɑz laɪk tʃeɪnɪŋ ə tɛmpəst ʌv wɪnd, ən wɑz dɪfəkəlt ivən wən i wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ən hɛlθi. naʊ ɪt wɑz nɪɹli ɪmpɑsəbəl.

"How odd," he heard Semirhage say, as if distant. He shook his head, still holding the One Power  - wrestling with it as he always had to with saidin, forcing that powerful, twisting flow of energy to his will. It was like chaining a tempest of wind, and was difficult even when he was strong and healthy. Now it was nearly impossible.

juz ɪt, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. kɪl əɹ waɪl wi kæn!

Use it, Lews Therin whispered. Kill her while we can!

əl nɑt kɪl ə wʊmən, ɹænd θɔt stʌbɝnli, ə fɪɡmən ʌv ə mɛmɹi fɹəm ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. ðəɾ ɪz ðə laɪn əl nɑt kɹɔs. . . .

I will not kill a woman, Rand thought stubbornly, a figment of a memory from the back of his mind. That is the line I will not cross. . . .

luz θɝɪn ɹɔɹd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk seɪɾɪn fɹəm ɹænd, bʌt wɪθaʊt səksɛs. ɪn fækt, ɹænd faʊn ðəɾ i kʊdn tʃænəl wɪlfəli ɛni mɔɹ ðən i kəd stɛp wɪθaʊt sɛmɝhɪdʒəz pɝmɪʃən.

Lews Therin roared, trying to take saidin from Rand, but without success. In fact, Rand found that he couldn't channel willfully any more than he could step without Semirhage's permission.

hi ɹaɪɾɪd hɪmsɛlf baɪ hɝ kəmænd, ðə ɹum ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ stɛɾi, ðə nɔziə ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ. ən ðən i bɪɡæn tə fɔɹm wivz, kɑmpləkeɪɾəd wʌnz ə spɪɹəɾ ən faɪɝ.

He righted himself by her command, the room growing more steady, the nausea retreating. And then he began to form weaves, complicated ones of Spirit and Fire.

"jɛs," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛd, ɔlmoʊs tə hɝsɛlf. "naʊ, ɪf aɪ kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ. . . . ðə meɪl weɪ ʌv duɪŋ ðɪs ɪz soʊ ɑd, səmtaɪmz."

"Yes," Semirhage said, almost to herself. "Now, if I can remember. . . . The male way of doing this is so odd, sometimes."

ɹænd meɪd ðə wivz, ðən pʊʃt əm təwɔɹd mɪn. "noʊ!" hi skɹimd əz i dɪd soʊ. "nɑt ðæt!"

Rand made the weaves, then pushed them toward Min. "No!" he screamed as he did so. "Not that!"

"ɑ, soʊ jə si," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛd. "ju wɝn soʊ dɪfəkəl tə bɹeɪk æftɝ ɔl."

"Ah, so you see," Semirhage said. "You weren't so difficult to break after all."

ðə wivz tʌtʃt mɪn ən ʃi ɹɪθd ɪn peɪn. ɹænd kəntɪnjud tə tʃænəl, tɪɹz spɹɪŋɪŋ tə hɪz aɪz əz i wɑz fɔɹs tə sɛn ðə kɑmplɛks wivz θɹu hɝ bɑɾi. ðeɪ bɹɔɾ æɡəni oʊnli, bʌt ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪt vɛɹi wɛl. sɛmɝhɪdʒ mʌst əv ɹilis mɪnz ɡæɡ, fəɹ ʃi bɪɡæn tə skɹim, wipɪŋ.

The weaves touched Min and she writhed in pain. Rand continued to channel, tears springing to his eyes as he was forced to send the complex weaves through her body. They brought agony only, but they did it very well. Semirhage must have released Min's gag, for she began to scream, weeping.

"pliz, ɹænd!" ʃi bɛɡd. "pliz!"

"Please, Rand!" she begged. "Please!"

ɹænd ɹɔɹɾ ɪn æŋɡɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑp, əneɪbəl tə. hi kəd fil mɪnz peɪn θɹu ðə bɑnd, fil ɪɾ əz i kɑzd ɪt.

Rand roared in anger, trying to stop, unable to. He could feel Min's pain through the bond, feel it as he caused it.

"stɑp ðɪs!" hi bɛloʊd.

"Stop this!" he bellowed.

"bɛɡ," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛd.

"Beg," Semirhage said.

"pliz," hi sɛd, wipɪŋ. "pliz, aɪ bɛɡ ju."

"Please," he said, weeping. "Please, I beg you."

sʌɾənli, hi stɑpt, ðə tɔɹtʃɝɪŋ wivz ənɹævəlɪŋ. mɪn hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, wɪmpɝɪŋ, aɪz deɪz fɹəm ðə ʃɑk ə peɪn. ɹænd tɝn ɝaʊnd, feɪsɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒ ən ðə smɔlɝ fɪɡjɝ ʌv ɛlzə bɪsaɪd hɝ. ðə blæk lʊk tɛɹəfaɪd, əz ɪf ʃid ɡɑɾən hɝsɛlf ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ ʃi hædn bɪn pɹipɛɹd fɔɹ.

Suddenly, he stopped, the torturing weaves unraveling. Min hung in the air, whimpering, eyes dazed from the shock of pain. Rand turned around, facing Semirhage and the smaller figure of Elza beside her. The Black looked terrified, as if she'd gotten herself into something she hadn't been prepared for.

"naʊ," ðə fɔɹseɪkən sɛd, "ju si ðət juv ɔlweɪz bɪn ɪntɛndəd tə sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd.

"Now," the Forsaken said, "you see that you have always been intended to serve the Great Lord.

wɪl liv ðɪs ɹum ən wɪl dil wɪð ðoʊz soʊ-kɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ɪmpɹɪzən mi. wɪl tʃɹævəl tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ən pɹɛzən jə tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, ən ðən ðɪs kən ɔl bi fɪnɪʃt."

We will leave this room and will deal with those so-called Aes Sedai who imprisoned me. We will Travel to Shayol Ghul and present you to the Great Lord, and then this can all be finished."

hi baʊɾ ɪz hɛd. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ aʊt! hi ɪmædʒən əɹ juzɪŋ ɪm tə tɛɹ θɹu ðə ɹæŋks ə hɪz oʊn mɛn. hi ɪmædʒən əm əfɹeɪd tə ətæk, lɛs ðeɪ hɑɹm hɪm. hi sɔ ðə blʌd, dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən i wəd kɑz. ən ɪt tʃɪl hɪm, tɝn ɪm tə aɪs ɪnsaɪd.

He bowed his head. There had to be a way out! He imagined her using him to tear through the ranks of his own men. He imagined them afraid to attack, lest they harm him. He saw the blood, death and destruction he would cause. And it chilled him, turned him to ice inside.

ðeɪv wʌn.

They have won.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɡlænst ət ðə dɔɹ, ðən tɝn bæk tə hɪm ən smaɪld. "bʌɾ aɪm əfɹeɪd wi mʌs dil wɪð əɹ fɝst. lɛɾ əs bi əbaʊɾ ɪt, ðɛn."

Semirhage glanced at the door, then turned back to him and smiled. "But I'm afraid we must deal with her first. Let us be about it, then."

ɹænd tɝn ən bɪɡæn tə wɔk təwɔɹd mɪn. "noʊ!" hi sɛd. "ju pɹɑməst ɪf aɪ bɛɡd - "

Rand turned and began to walk toward Min. "No!" he said. "You promised if I begged - "

"aɪ pɹɑməs nʌθɪŋ," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛd wɪð ə læf. "ju bɛɡd kwaɪt pɹɪɾəli, luz θɝɪn, bʌɾ aɪ hæv tʃoʊzən tə ɪɡnɔɹ jəɹ pliz. jə kən ɹilis seɪɾɪn, haʊɛvɝ. ðɪs nidz tə bi sʌmwʌt mɔɹ pɝsənəl."

"I promised nothing," Semirhage said with a laugh. "You begged quite prettily, Lews Therin, but I have chosen to ignore your pleas. You can release saidin, however. This needs to be somewhat more personal."

seɪɾɪn wɪŋkt əweɪ, ən ɹænd fɛl ðə wɪðdʒɹɔəl ə paʊɝ wɪð ɹəɡɹɛt. ðə wɝl simd mɔɹ dʌl ɝaʊn hɪm. hi stɛpt ʌp tə mɪn, hɝ pliɾɪŋ aɪz miɾɪŋ hɪz. ðən i pɹɛst ɪz hæn tə hɝ θɹoʊt, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪt, ən bɪɡæn tə skwiz.

Saidin winked away, and Rand felt the withdrawal of power with regret. The world seemed more dull around him. He stepped up to Min, her pleading eyes meeting his. Then he pressed his hand to her throat, gripping it, and began to squeeze.

"noʊ. . . ." hi wɪspɝɾ ɪn hɔɹɝ əz ɪz hænd, əɡɛnst ɪz wɪl, kʌɾ ɔf əɹ ɛɹ. mɪn stʌmbəld, ən i ənwɪlɪŋli fɔɹst əɹ daʊn tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, izəli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ əɹ stʃɹʌɡəlz. hi lumd əbʌv hɝ, pɹɛsɪŋ ɪz hæn əɡɛnst əɹ θɹoʊt, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪɾ ən tʃoʊkɪŋ hɝ. ʃi lʊkt ət hɪm, aɪz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə bʌlʒ.

"No. . . ." he whispered in horror as his hand, against his will, cut off her air. Min stumbled, and he unwillingly forced her down to the ground, easily ignoring her struggles. He loomed above her, pressing his hand against her throat, gripping it and choking her. She looked at him, eyes beginning to bulge.

ðɪs kæn bi hæpənɪŋ.

This can't be happening.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ læft.

Semirhage laughed.

aɪlaɪɛnə! luz θɝɪn weɪld. oʊ, laɪt! aɪv kɪl hɝ!

Ilyena! Lews Therin wailed. Oh, Light! I've killed her!

ɹænd skwiz hɑɹɾɝ, linɪŋ daʊn fəɹ lɛvɝɪdʒ, hɪz fɪŋɡɝz skwizɪŋ mɪnz skɪn ən pʊʃɪŋ daʊn ɑn əɹ θɹoʊt. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf i ɡɹɪpt ɪz oʊn hɑɹt, ən ðə wɝl bɪkeɪm blæk ɝaʊn hɪm, ɛvɹiθɪŋ dɑɹkən ɪksɛp fəɹ mɪn. hi kəd fil əɹ pʌls θɹɑbɪŋ bɪniθ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz.

Rand squeezed harder, leaning down for leverage, his fingers squeezing Min's skin and pushing down on her throat. It was as if he gripped his own heart, and the world became black around him, everything darkened except for Min. He could feel her pulse throbbing beneath his fingers.

ðoʊz bjuɾəfəl dɑɹk aɪz ə hɝz wɑtʃt hɪm, lʌvɪŋ ɪm ivən əz i kɪl hɝ.

Those beautiful dark eyes of hers watched him, loving him even as he killed her.

ðɪs kæn bi hæpənɪŋ!

This can't be happening!

aɪv kɪl hɝ!

I've killed her!

aɪm mæd!

I'm mad!

aɪlaɪɛnə!

Ilyena!

ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ aʊt! hæd tə bi! ɹænd wɑntəd tə kloʊz ɪz aɪz, bʌɾ i kʊdnt. ʃi wʊdn lɛɾ ɪm - nɑt sɛmɝhɪdʒ, bʌt mɪn. ʃi hɛld ɪz aɪz wɪð əɹ oʊn, tɪɹz laɪnɪŋ əɹ tʃiks, dɑɹk, kɝl hɛɹ dɪʃɛvəld. soʊ bjuɾəfəl.

There had to be a way out! Had to be! Rand wanted to close his eyes, but he couldn't. She wouldn't let him - not Semirhage, but Min. She held his eyes with her own, tears lining her cheeks, dark, curled hair disheveled. So beautiful.

hi skɹæmbəl fəɹ seɪɾɪn, bʌt kəd nɑt teɪk ɪt. hi tʃɹaɪd wɪð ɛvɹi bɪɾ ʌv wɪl i hæd tə ɹɪlæks ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, bʌt ðeɪ dʒʌs kəntɪnjud tə skwiz. hi fɛl hɔɹɝ, hi fɛlt əɹ peɪn. mɪnz feɪs ɡɹu pɝpəl, hɝ aɪz flʌɾɝd.

He scrambled for saidin, but could not take it. He tried with every bit of will he had to relax his fingers, but they just continued to squeeze. He felt horror, he felt her pain. Min's face grew purple, her eyes fluttered.

ɹænd weɪld. ðɪs kæn bi hæpənɪŋ! əl nɑt də ðɪs əɡɛn!

Rand wailed. THIS CAN'T BE HAPPENING! I WILL NOT DO THIS AGAIN!

sʌmθɪŋ snæpt ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm. hi ɡɹu koʊld; ðən ðət koʊlnəs vænɪʃt, ən i kəd fil nʌθɪŋ. noʊ ɪmoʊʃən. noʊ æŋɡɝ.

Something snapped inside of him. He grew cold; then that coldness vanished, and he could feel nothing. No emotion. No anger.

ət ðət moʊmən i ɡɹu əwɛɹ ʌv ə stʃɹeɪnʒ fɔɹs. ɪt wɑz laɪk ə ɹɛzəvwɑɹ ʌv wɔɾɝ, bɔɪlɪŋ ən tʃɝnɪŋ dʒʌs bɪɑn ɪz vju. hi ɹitʃt təwɔɹɾ ɪt wɪð ɪz maɪnd.

At that moment he grew aware of a strange force. It was like a reservoir of water, boiling and churning just beyond his view. He reached toward it with his mind.

ə klaʊɾəd feɪs flæʃt bɪfɔɹ ɹændz oʊn, wʌn huz fitʃɝz i kʊdn kwaɪt meɪk aʊt. ɪt wɑz ɡɔn ɪn ə moʊmənt.

A clouded face flashed before Rand's own, one whose features he couldn't quite make out. It was gone in a moment.

ən ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf fɪld wɪð ən eɪliən paʊɝ. nɑt seɪɾɪn, nɑt seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls.

And Rand found himself filled with an alien power. Not saidin, not saidar, but something else.

sʌmθɪŋ hid nɛvɝ fɛl bɪfɔɹ.

Something he'd never felt before.

oʊ, laɪt, luz θɝɪn sʌɾənli skɹimd. ðæts ɪmpɑsəbəl! wi kæn juz ɪt! kæst ɪɾ əweɪ!

Oh, Light, Lews Therin suddenly screamed. That's impossible! We can't use it! Cast it away!

ðəɾ ɪz dɛθ wi hoʊld, dɛθ ən bɪtʃɹeɪəl.

That is death we hold, death and betrayal.

ɪts hɪm.

It is HIM.

ɹænd kloʊzd ɪz aɪz əz i nɛlt əbʌv mɪn, ðən i tʃænəl ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ, ənnoʊn fɔɹs. ɛnɝdʒi ən laɪf sɝdʒ θɹu hɪm, ə tɔɹən ə paʊɝ laɪk seɪɾɪn, oʊnli tɛn taɪmz əz swiɾ ən ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz əz vaɪələnt. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm əlaɪv, meɪɾ ɪm ɹilaɪz ðət hid nɛvɝ bɪn əlaɪv bɪfɔɹ. ɪt ɡeɪv ɪm sətʃ stʃɹɛŋkθ əz hid nɛvɝ ɪmædʒənd. ɪt ɹaɪvəld, ivən, ðə paʊɝ hid hɛld wən dʒɹɔɪŋ fɹəm ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl.

Rand closed his eyes as he knelt above Min, then he channeled the strange, unknown force. Energy and life surged through him, a torrent of power like saidin, only ten times as sweet and a hundred times as violent. It made him alive, made him realize that he'd never been alive before. It gave him such strength as he'd never imagined. It rivaled, even, the power he'd held when drawing from the Choedan Kal.

hi skɹimd, ɪn boʊθ ɹæptʃɝ ən ɹeɪdʒ, ən woʊv ɪnɔɹməs spɪɹz ə faɪɝ ən ɛɹ. hi slæm ðə wivz əɡɛns ðə kɑlɝ əɾ ɪz nɛk, ən ðə ɹum ɪksploʊɾəd wɪð fleɪmz ən bɪts ə moʊltən mɛɾəl, itʃ wʌn dɪstɪŋk tə ɹænd. hi kəd fil itʃ ʃɑɹɾ ə mɛɾəl blæst əweɪ fɹəm ɪz nɛk, wɔɹpɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɪð ɪts hit, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ smoʊk əz ɪt hɪɾ ə wɔl əɹ ðə flɔɹ. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən ɹilis mɪn. ʃi ɡæspt ən sɑbd.

He screamed, in both rapture and rage, and wove enormous spears of Fire and Air. He slammed the weaves against the collar at his neck, and the room exploded with flames and bits of molten metal, each one distinct to Rand. He could feel each shard of metal blast away from his neck, warping the air with its heat, trailing smoke as it hit a wall or the floor. He opened his eyes and released Min. She gasped and sobbed.

ɹænd stʊɾ ən tɝnd, waɪt-hɑt mæɡmə ɪn ɪz veɪnz - əz wən sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd tɔɹtʃɝd hɪm, jɛt sʌmhaʊ ɑpəzət. əz peɪnfəl əz ðɪs wɑz, ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ pjʊɹ ɛkstəsi.

Rand stood and turned, white-hot magma in his veins - as when Semirhage had tortured him, yet somehow opposite. As painful as this was, it was also pure ecstasy.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ lʊkt ʌɾɝli ʃɑkt. "bʌt . . . ðæts ɪmpɑsəbəl . . ." ʃi sɛd. "aɪ fɛl nʌθɪŋ. jə kænt - " ʃi lʊkt ʌp, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð waɪɾ aɪz. "ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ. waɪ hæv jə bɪtʃɹeɪd mi, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd? waɪ?"

Semirhage looked utterly shocked. "But . . . that's impossible . . ." she said. "I felt nothing. You can't - " She looked up, staring at him with wide eyes. "The True Power. Why have you betrayed me, Great Lord? Why?"

ɹænd ɹeɪzd ə hæn ænd, fɪld wɪð ðə paʊɝ i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, woʊv ə sɪŋɡəl wiv. ə bɑɹ ə pjʊɹ waɪt laɪt, ə klɛnzɪŋ faɪɝ, bɝs fɹəm ɪz hæn ən stʃɹʌk sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɪn ðə tʃɛst. ʃi flæʃt ən vænɪʃt, livɪŋ ə feɪn æftɝɪmɪdʒ tə ɹændz vɪʒən. hɝ bɹeɪslət dʒɹɑp tə ðə flɔɹ.

Rand raised a hand and, filled with the power he did not understand, wove a single weave. A bar of pure white light, a cleansing fire, burst from his hand and struck Semirhage in the chest. She flashed and vanished, leaving a faint afterimage to Rand's vision. Her bracelet dropped to the floor.

ɛlzə ɹæn təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ. ʃi vænɪʃt bɪfɔɹ ənʌðɝ bɑɹ ə laɪt, hɝ ɪntaɪɝ fɪɡjɝ bɪkʌmɪŋ laɪt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. hɝ bɹeɪslət dʒɹɑp tə ðə flɔɹ, əz wɛl, ðə wɪmən u hæd hɛld əm bɝn kəmplitli fɹəm ðə pæɾɝn.

Elza ran toward the door. She vanished before another bar of light, her entire figure becoming light for a moment. Her bracelet dropped to the floor, as well, the women who had held them burned completely from the Pattern.

wʌɾ əv jə dʌn? luz θɝɪn æskt. oʊ, laɪt. bɛɾɝ tə hæv kɪld əɡɛn ðən tə də ðɪs. . . . oʊ, laɪt. wəɹ dumd.

What have you done? Lews Therin asked. Oh, Light. Better to have killed again than to do this. . . . Oh, Light. We are doomed.

ɹænd seɪvɝd ðə paʊɝ fəɹ ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ, ðən - ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli - lɛɾ ɪt dʒɹɑp əweɪ. hi wʊɾə hɛld ɑn, bʌɾ i wɑz sɪmpli tu ɪɡzɔstəd. ðə vænɪʃɪŋ ʌv ɪt lɛft ɪm nʌm.

Rand savored the power for a moment longer, then - regretfully - let it drop away. He would have held on, but he was simply too exhausted. The vanishing of it left him numb.

əɹ . . . noʊ. ðət nʌmnəs hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ hid hɛld. hi tɝn ɝaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət mɪn, hu kɔf kwaɪətli ən ɹʌbd əɹ nɛk. ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət hɪm, ən simd əfɹeɪd. hi daʊɾɪd ðət ʃi wəɾ ɛvɝ si hɪm ðə seɪm weɪ əɡɛn.

Or . . . no. That numbness had nothing to do with the power he'd held. He turned around, looking down at Min, who coughed quietly and rubbed her neck. She looked up at him, and seemed afraid. He doubted that she would ever see him the same way again.

hi hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ; ðəɹ hæɾ ɪndid bɪn sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ kəd də tə hɪm. hi hæd fɛl hɪmsɛlf kɪlɪŋ wʌn i lʌv dɪɹli. bɪfɔɹ, wən hid dʌn ɪɾ əz luz θɝɪn, hi hæd bɪn mæɾ ən əneɪbəl tə kəntʃɹoʊl hɪmsɛlf. hi kəd bɛɹli ɹɪmɛmbɝ sleɪɪŋ aɪlaɪɛnə, əz ɪf θɹu ə klaʊɾəd dʒɹim. hid ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ i hæd dʌn oʊnli æftɝ ɪʃəml hæɾ əweɪkən hɪm.

He had been wrong; there had indeed been something more that Semirhage could do to him. He had felt himself killing one he loved dearly. Before, when he'd done it as Lews Therin, he had been mad and unable to control himself. He could barely remember slaying Ilyena, as if through a clouded dream. He'd realized what he had done only after Ishamael had awakened him.

faɪnəli, naʊ, hi nu pɹɪsaɪsli wʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk tə wɑtʃ əz i kɪl ðoʊz i lʌvd.

Finally, now, he knew precisely what it was like to watch as he killed those he loved.

"ɪɾ ɪz dʌn," ɹænd wɪspɝd.

"It is done," Rand whispered.

"wʌt?" mɪn æskt, kɑfɪŋ əɡɛn.

"What?" Min asked, coughing again.

"ðə læs ðət kəd bi dʌn tə mi," hi sɛd, sɝpɹaɪzd əɾ ɪz oʊn kɑmnəs. "ðeɪ hæv teɪkən ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm mi naʊ."

"The last that could be done to me," he said, surprised at his own calmness. "They have taken everything from me now."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ, ɹænd?" mɪn æskt. ʃi ɹʌbd əɹ nɛk əɡɛn. bɹuzəz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃoʊ.

"What are you saying, Rand?" Min asked. She rubbed her neck again. Bruises were beginning to show.

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz - faɪnəli - vɔɪsəz saʊndəɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd. pɝhæps ði æʃəmən hæd sɛnst ɪm tʃænəlɪŋ wən hid tɔɹtʃɝd mɪn.

He shook his head as - finally - voices sounded in the hallway outside. Perhaps the Asha'man had sensed him channeling when he'd tortured Min.

"aɪ hæv meɪd maɪ tʃɔɪs, mɪn," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ. "ju hæv æsk fəɹ flɛksəbɪləɾi ən læftɝ fɹəm mi, bʌt sətʃ θɪŋz ɑɹ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ maɪn tə ɡɪv. aɪm sɑɹi."

"I have made my choice, Min," he said, turning toward the door. "You have asked for flexibility and laughter from me, but such things are no longer mine to give. I am sorry."

wʌns, wiks əɡoʊ, hi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ i mʌs bɪkʌm stʃɹɔŋɝ - wɛɹ i hæd bɪn aɪɝn, hi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bɪkʌm stil. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət stil wɑz tu wik.

Once, weeks ago, he had decided that he must become stronger - where he had been iron, he had decided to become steel. It appeared that steel was too weak.

hi wəd bi hɑɹɾɝ, naʊ. hi ʌndɝstʊd haʊ. wɛɹ i hæd wʌns bɪn stil, hi bɪkeɪm sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. fɹəm naʊ ɑn, hi wɑz kwəndɪlɝ. hi hæɾ ɛntɝɾ ə pleɪs laɪk ðə vɔɪd ðət tæm hæd tʃɹeɪn ɪm tə sik, soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. bʌt wɪðɪn ðɪs vɔɪɾ i hæd noʊ ɪmoʊʃən. nʌn əɾ ɔl.

He would be harder, now. He understood how. Where he had once been steel, he became something else. From now on, he was cuendillar. He had entered a place like the void that Tam had trained him to seek, so long ago. But within this void he had no emotion. None at all.

ðeɪ kəd nɑt bɹeɪk əɹ bɛn hɪm.

They could not break or bend him.

ɪt wɑz dʌn.

It was done.

The Warders should have noticed that something was wrong anyway - they'd have to interrogate the men to see what they had felt. But there was likely a correlation.

deɪdʒiən hæd noʊ lɪvɪŋ wɔɹɾɝ. kædzueɪn fɛlt ə stæb ə ɹəɡɹɛt fəɹ ðə plɛzən sɪstɝ, bʌt ʃʌvd ɪɾ əsaɪd. noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɪt naʊ.

Daigian had no living Warder. Cadsuane felt a stab of regret for the pleasant sister, but shoved it aside. No time for it now.

kædzueɪn nɑɾəd kɹɑsli. ʌv ɔl ðə naɪts tə bi aʊt vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz ɪn ðɛɹ tɛns! sɔɹɪliə ən ə smɔl ɡɹup ə ðɛm fɑloʊd bɪhaɪnd nɛɹɪʃmə, ən kædzueɪn dɪdn dɛɹ sloʊ hɝ peɪs, lɛs ði il wɪmən tʃɹæmpəl əɹ ɪn ðɛɹ heɪs tə si ælθɹ.

Cadsuane nodded crossly. Of all the nights to be out visiting the Wise Ones in their tents! Sorilea and a small group of them followed behind Narishma, and Cadsuane didn't dare slow her pace, lest the Aiel women trample her in their haste to see al'Thor.

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz, ðən spɛd daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ təwɔɹɾ ælθɹz ɹum. haʊ kəɾ i hæv ɡɑɾən hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ðɪs mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl, əɡɛn! ən haʊ hæd ðət blæstəd fɔɹseɪkən ɡɑɾən fɹi ʌv əɹ sɛl? sʌmwʌn mʌst əv hɛlp hɝ, bʌt ðət mɛn ə dɑɹkfɹɛn ɪn ðɛɹ kæmp. ɪt wɑzn ənlaɪkli - ɪf dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪɡzɪstəɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ðən ðeɪ kəɾ əndaʊɾɪdli bi faʊn hɪɹ. bʌt wʌt dɑɹkfɹɛn kəɾ ɪnkəpæsɪteɪt θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ? ʃʊɹli tʃænəlɪŋ ɑn ðət lɛvəl ʃʊɾə bɪn fɛl baɪ ɛvɹi sɪstɝ əɹ æʃəmən ɪn ðə kæmp.

They reached the top of the stairs, then sped down the hallway toward al'Thor's room. How could he have gotten himself into this much trouble, again! And how had that blasted Forsaken gotten free of her cell? Someone must have helped her, but that meant a Darkfriend in their camp. It wasn't unlikely - if Darkfriends existed in the White Tower, then they could undoubtedly be found here. But what Darkfriend could incapacitate three Aes Sedai? Surely channeling on that level should have been felt by every sister or Asha'man in the camp.

"wɑz ðə ti ɪnvɑlvd?" kædzueɪn æsk mɛɹaɪs kwaɪətli.

"Was the tea involved?" Cadsuane asked Merise quietly.

"nɑt ðət wi kən tɛl," ðə ɡɹin ɹɪplaɪd. "wil noʊ mɔɹ wən ði ʌðɝ tu weɪk. ðeɪ fɛl ʌnkɑnʃəs əz sun əz wi bɹɔɾ əm aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ tʃɹæns."

kædzueɪn nɑɾəd. ælθɹz dɔɹ wɑz oʊpən, ən meɪɾənz swɔɹmd aʊtsaɪɾ ɪt laɪk wɑsps u hæd dʒʌs dɪskʌvɝd ðɛɹ nɛst wɑz ɡɔn. kædzueɪn kʊdn seɪ ðət ʃi bleɪm ðɛm. əpɛɹənli, ælθɹ hæd sɛd lɪɾəl ʌv wʌt hæd hæpənd. ðə ful bɔɪ wɑz lʌki tə stɪl bi əlaɪv! wʌɾ ə laɪt- kɝs mɛs, kædzueɪn θɔt, pæsɪŋ ðə meɪɾənz ən ɛntɝɪŋ ðə tʃeɪmbɝ.

ə smɔl nɑɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ klʌstɝɾ ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, spikɪŋ kwaɪətli. sɝin, ɛɹiən, bɛldaɪn - ɔl ə ðoʊz ɪn ðə kæmp u wɝn iðɝ dɛɾ əɹ ɪnkəpæsɪteɪɾɪd. ɪksɛpt ɛlzə. wɛɹ wɑz ɛlzə?

ðə θɹi nɑɾəd tə kædzueɪn əz ʃi ɛntɝd, bʌt ʃi spɛɹɾ əm bɛɹli ə ɡlæns. mɪn sæɾ ɑn ðə bɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ nɛk, aɪz ɹɛd, ʃɔɹt hɛɹ dɪʃɛvəld, feɪs peɪl. ælθɹ stʊd bɪsaɪd ði oʊpən fɑɹ wɪndoʊ, lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ət ðə naɪt, hɪz hæn klæspɪŋ ɪz stʌmp bɪhaɪn hɪm. hɪz koʊt leɪ ɹʌmpəld ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ən i stʊɾ ɪn waɪt ʃɝtslivz, ə kul wɪn bloʊɪŋ ɪn ən ɹʌfəlɪŋ ɪz ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ.

Al'Thor stood beside the open far window, looking out at the night, his hand clasping his stump behind him. His coat lay rumpled on the floor, and he stood in white shirtsleeves, a cool wind blowing in and ruffling his red-gold hair.

nɪneɪiv wɑtʃt hɪm, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

faɪnəli, hi tɝnd, lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. ʃi tʊk ən ɪnvɑləntɛɹi stɛp bækwɝd, ðoʊ ʃi kʊdn seɪ waɪ. hi wɑz stɪl ðə seɪm fulɪʃ bɔɪ. tu tɔl, tu sɛlf-kɑnfəɾənt, ən tu blʌnt-hɛɾəd. ðəɹ wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ sɝɛnəɾi əbaʊɾ ɪm naʊ, bʌɾ ɪt hæɾ ə dɑɹk ɛdʒ. laɪk ðə sɝɛnəɾi wʌn sɔ ɪn ði aɪz ʌv ə kəndɛmd mæn ðə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ i stɛpt ʌp tə ðə hæŋmənz nus.

"Narishma," Rand said, looking past Cadsuane. "I have a weave for you. Memorize it; I will show it to you only once." With that, al'Thor put his hand out to the side and a bar of brilliant white fire shot from between his fingers and struck his coat, which lay on the floor. It vanished in a burst of light.

kædzueɪn hɪst. "aɪ toʊl jə nɛvɝ tə juz ðət wiv, bɔɪ! jəl nɛvɝ də soʊ əɡɛn. dʒju hɪɹ mi! ðɪs ɪz nɑt - "

Cadsuane hissed. "I told you never to use that weave, boy! You will never do so again. Do you hear me! This is not - "

"ðæɾ ɪz ðə wiv wi mʌs juz wən faɪɾɪŋ fɔɹseɪkən, nɛɹɪʃmə," ælθɹ sɛd, hɪz kwaɪət vɔɪs kʌɾɪŋ stʃɹeɪt θɹu kædzueɪnz. "ɪf wi kɪl əm wɪð ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ðeɪ kən bi ɹibɔɹn. ɪts ə deɪnʒɝəs tul, bʌt stɪl dʒʌst ə tul. laɪk ɛni ʌðɝ."

"That is the weave we must use when fighting Forsaken, Narishma," al'Thor said, his quiet voice cutting straight through Cadsuane's. "If we kill them with anything else, they can be reborn. It is a dangerous tool, but still just a tool. Like any other."

"ɪɾ ɪz fɔɹbɪɾən," kædzueɪn sɛd.

"It is forbidden," Cadsuane said.

"aɪ hæv dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ ɪts nɑt," ælθɹ sɛd kɑmli.

"I have decided that it is not," al'Thor said calmly.

"ju doʊn əv ɛni aɪdiə wʌt ðət wiv kən du! jəɹ ə tʃaɪl pleɪɪŋ wɪð - "

"You don't have any idea what that weave can do! You're a child playing with - "

"aɪ hæv sin bɑlfaɪɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪ sɪɾiz," ælθɹ sɛd, aɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɔntəd. "aɪ hæv sin θaʊzənz bɝn fɹəm ðə pæɾɝn baɪ ɪts pjʊɹəfaɪɪŋ fleɪmz. ɪf jə kɔl mi ə tʃaɪld, kædzueɪn, ðən wʌɾ ɑɹ ðoʊz ə jə hu ɑɹ θaʊzənz ə jɪɹz maɪ dʒunjɝz?"

"I have seen balefire destroy cities," al'Thor said, eyes growing haunted. "I have seen thousands burned from the Pattern by its purifying flames. If you call me a child, Cadsuane, then what are those of you who are thousands of years my juniors?"

hi mɛɾ əɹ ɡeɪz. laɪt! wʌt hæd hæpən tə hɪm? ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl tə kəlɛkt əɹ θɔts. "soʊ sɛmɝhɪdʒ ɪz dɛd?"

He met her gaze. Light! What had happened to him? She struggled to collect her thoughts. "So Semirhage is dead?"

"wɝs ðən dɛd," ælθɹ sɛd. "æn fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ɔf, ɪn mɛni weɪz, aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk."

"Worse than dead," al'Thor said. "And far better off, in many ways, I should think."

"wɛl, ðɛn. aɪ səpoʊz wi kən ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð - "

"Well, then. I suppose we can get on with - "

"du jə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðæt, kædzueɪn?" ælθɹ sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ təwɔɹd sʌmθɪŋ mətælɪk sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə bɛd, moʊsli hɪɾən baɪ ðə ʃits.

"Do you recognize that, Cadsuane?" al'Thor said, nodding toward something metallic sitting on the bed, mostly hidden by the sheets.

hɛzɪɾəntli ʃi wɔk fɔɹwɝd. sɔɹɪliə lʊkt oʊvɝ, ɪkspɹɛʃən ənɹiɾəbəl. əpɛɹənli, ʃi dɪdnt wɪʃ tə bi dʒɹɔn ɪndə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən wən ælθɹ wɑz ɪn sətʃ ə mud. kædzueɪn dɪdn bleɪm hɝ.

Hesitantly she walked forward. Sorilea looked over, expression unreadable. Apparently, she didn't wish to be drawn into the conversation when al'Thor was in such a mood. Cadsuane didn't blame her.

kædzueɪn pʊl bæk ðə ʃits, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə fəmɪljɝ pɛɹ ə bɹeɪslɪts. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kɑlɝ.

Cadsuane pulled back the sheets, revealing a familiar pair of bracelets. There was no collar.

"ɪmpɑsəbəl," ʃi wɪspɝd.

"Impossible," she whispered.

"ðæɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ əsumd," ælθɹ sɛɾ ɪn ðət tɛɹəbli kɑm vɔɪs ə hɪz. "aɪ toʊl maɪsɛlf ðəɾ ɪɾ ɑbviəsli kʊdn bi wʌn ə ðə seɪm tɛɹæŋɡɹil aɪ ɹɪlɪŋkwɪʃt tə ju. jə pɹɑməs ðeɪ wəd bi pɹətɛktəɾ ən hɪɾən."

"That is what I assumed," al'Thor said in that terribly calm voice of his. "I told myself that it obviously couldn't be one of the same ter'angreal I relinquished to you. You promised they would be protected and hidden."

"wɛl, ðɛn," kædzueɪn sɛd, ənnɝvd. ʃi kʌvɝd ðə θɪŋz bæk ʌp. "ðæɾ ɪz sɛɾəld ðɛn."

"Well, then," Cadsuane said, unnerved. She covered the things back up. "That is settled then."

"ɪɾ ɪz. aɪ sɛn pipəl tə jəɹ ɹum. tɛl mi, ɪz ðɪs bɑks wɛɹ jə wɝ kipɪŋ ðə bɹeɪslɪts? wi faʊn ɪɾ oʊpən ɑn ðə flɔɹ ə jəɹ kɔɹɾɝz."

"It is. I sent people to your room. Tell me, is this box where you were keeping the bracelets? We found it open on the floor of your quarters."

eɪ meɪɾən bɹɔɾ aʊɾ ə fəmɪljɝ oʊk bɑks. ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm wʌn, ɑbviəsli. kædzueɪn tɝn təwɔɹɾ ɪm ɪn æŋɡɝ. "ju sɝtʃt maɪ ɹum!"

A Maiden brought out a familiar oak box. It was the same one, obviously. Cadsuane turned toward him in anger. "You searched my room!"

"aɪ wɑz ʌnəwɛɹ ðət jə wɝ vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz," ælθɹ sɛd. hi ɡeɪv ə smɔl nɑɾ ə ɹɪspɛk tə sɔɹɪliə ən æmɪz, wɪtʃ ðeɪ hɛzɪɾəntli ɹɪtɝnd. "aɪ sɛn sɝvəns tə tʃɛk ɑn ju, əz aɪ fɪɹd ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ maɪɾ əv tʃɹaɪd fəɹ ɹivɛnʒ ɑn ju."

"I was unaware that you were visiting the Wise Ones," al'Thor said. He gave a small nod of respect to Sorilea and Amys, which they hesitantly returned. "I sent servants to check on you, as I feared that Semirhage might have tried for revenge on you."

"ðeɪ ʃʊdn əv tʌtʃt ðɪs," kædzueɪn sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ðə bɑks fɹəm ðə meɪɾən. "ɪt wɑz pɹipɛɹd wɪð vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəkət wɔɹdz."

"They shouldn't have touched this," Cadsuane said, taking the box from the Maiden. "It was prepared with very intricate wards."

"nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəkəɾ ɪnʌf," ælθɹ sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. hi stɪl stʊd baɪ ðət dɑɹkənd wɪndoʊ, lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə kæmp.

"Not intricate enough," al'Thor said, turning away from her. He still stood by that darkened window, looking out over the camp.

ðə ɹum fɛl saɪlənt. nɛɹɪʃmə hæd bɪn æskɪŋ kwaɪətli æftɝ mɪnz hɛlθ, bʌɾ i fɛl saɪlənt wən ælθɹ stɑp spikɪŋ. ɹænd ɑbviəsli fɛl ðət kædzueɪn wɑz ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ðə meɪl æɾəm biɪŋ stoʊlən, bʌt ðət wɑz pɹɪpɑstɝəs. ʃi hæd pɹipɛɹd ðə bɛst wɔɹd ʃi nu, bʌɾ u nu wʌt nɑlədʒ ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd fəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ pæst wɔɹdz?

The room fell silent. Narishma had been asking quietly after Min's health, but he fell silent when al'Thor stopped speaking. Rand obviously felt that Cadsuane was responsible for the male a'dam being stolen, but that was preposterous. She had prepared the best ward she knew, but who knew what knowledge the Forsaken had for getting past wards?

haʊ hæɾ ælθɹ sɝvaɪvd? ən wʌɾ ə ði ʌðɝ kɑntɛns ə ðət bɑks? dɪɾ ælθɹ naʊ hæv ði æksɛs ki, əɹ hæd ðə stætʃuɛt bɪn teɪkən baɪ sɛmɝhɪdʒ? dɪd kædzueɪn dɛɹ æsk? ðə saɪləns kəntɪnjud. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ?" ʃi faɪnəli æskt wɪð ɔl ðə bɹəvɑɾoʊ ʃi kəd sʌmən. "du jə ɪkspɛkt ən əpɑlədʒi fɹəm mi?"

How had al'Thor survived? And what of the other contents of that box? Did al'Thor now have the access key, or had the statuette been taken by Semirhage? Did Cadsuane dare ask? The silence continued. "What are you waiting for?" she finally asked with all the bravado she could summon. "Do you expect an apology from me?"

"fɹʌm ju?" ælθɹ æskt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hjumɝ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs, dʒʌs ðə seɪm koʊld ivənnəs. "noʊ, aɪ səspɛk ðəɾ aɪ kəd sunɝ ɪkstʃɹækt ən əpɑlədʒi fɹəm ə stoʊn ðən fɹəm ju."

"From you?" al'Thor asked. There was no humor in his voice, just the same cold evenness. "No, I suspect that I could sooner extract an apology from a stone than from you."

"ðɛn - "

"Then - "

"ju ɑɹ ɛɡzaɪl fɹəm maɪ saɪt, kædzueɪn," hi sɛd sɔfli. "ɪf aɪ si jəɹ feɪs əɡɛn æftɝ tənaɪt, əl kɪl ju."

"You are exiled from my sight, Cadsuane," he said softly. "If I see your face again after tonight, I will kill you."

"ɹænd, noʊ!" mɪn sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd. hi dɪdn tɝn təwɔɹd hɝ.

"Rand, no!" Min said, standing up beside the bed. He didn't turn toward her.

kædzueɪn fɛlt ən ɪmiɾiət stæb ə pænɪk, bʌt ʃʌvd ɪɾ əsaɪd wɪð əɹ æŋɡɝ. "wʌt?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "ðɪs ɪz fulɪʃnəs, bɔɪ. aɪ. . . ."

Cadsuane felt an immediate stab of panic, but shoved it aside with her anger. "What?" she demanded. "This is foolishness, boy. I. . . ."

hi tɝnd, ən əɡɛn ðət ɡeɪz ə hɪz meɪɾ əɹ tʃɹeɪl ɔf. ðəɹ wɑz ə deɪnʒɝ tə ɪt, ə ʃæɾoʊi kæs tə hɪz aɪz ðət stʃɹʌk əɹ wɪð mɔɹ fɪɹ ðən ʃid θɔɾ əɹ eɪdʒɪŋ hɑɹt kəd sʌmən. əz ʃi wɑtʃt, ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn ɪm sim tə wɔɹp, ən ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs θɪŋk ðət ðə ɹum hæd ɡɹoʊn dɑɹkɝ.

He turned, and again that gaze of his made her trail off. There was a danger to it, a shadowy cast to his eyes that struck her with more fear than she'd thought her aging heart could summon. As she watched, the air around him seemed to warp, and she could almost think that the room had grown darker.

"bʌt. . . ." ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf stʌɾɝɪŋ. "bʌt jə doʊn kɪl wɪmən. ɛvɹiwʌn noʊz ɪt. jə kən hɑɹdli pʊt ðə meɪɾənz ɪndə deɪnʒɝ fəɹ fɪɹ ə ðɛm ɡɛɾɪŋ hɝt!"

"But. . . ." She found herself stuttering. "But you don't kill women. Everyone knows it. You can hardly put the Maidens into danger for fear of them getting hurt!"

"aɪ hæv bɪn fɔɹs tə ɹɪvaɪz ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɪnkləneɪʃən," ælθɹ sɛd. "æz ə tənaɪt."

"I have been forced to revise that particular inclination," al'Thor said. "As of tonight."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"kædzueɪn," hi sɛd sɔfli, "du jə bɪliv ðəɾ aɪ kəd kɪl ju? ɹaɪt hɪɹ, ɹaɪt naʊ, wɪθaʊt juzɪŋ ə sɔɹɾ əɹ ðə paʊɝ? dʒju bɪliv ðəɾ ɪf aɪ sɪmpli wɪld ɪt, ðə pæɾɝn wəd bɛn ɝaʊn mi ən stɑp jəɹ hɑɹt? baɪ . . . koʊɪnsɪɾəns?"

"Cadsuane," he said softly, "do you believe that I could kill you? Right here, right now, without using a sword or the Power? Do you believe that if I simply willed it, the Pattern would bend around me and stop your heart? By . . . coincidence?"

biɪŋ tɑvɝən dɪdnt wɝk ðət weɪ. laɪt! ɪt dɪdnt, dɪɾ ɪt? hi kʊdn bɛn ðə vɛɹi pæɾɝn tə hɪz wɪl, kəd hi?

Being ta'veren didn't work that way. Light! It didn't, did it? He couldn't bend the very Pattern to his will, could he?

ən jɛt, miɾɪŋ ɪz aɪz, ʃi dɪd bɪliv. əɡɛnst ɔl lɑdʒɪk, ʃi lʊkt ɪn ðoʊz aɪz ən nu ðəɾ ɪf ʃi dɪdn liv, ʃi wəd daɪ.

And yet, meeting his eyes, she did believe. Against all logic, she looked in those eyes and knew that if she didn't leave, she would die.

ʃi nɑɾəd sloʊli, heɪɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf, stʃɹeɪnʒli wik.

She nodded slowly, hating herself, strangely weak.

hi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, lʊkɪŋ bæk aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ. "bi sɝɾən ðəɾ aɪ də nɑt si jəɹ feɪs.

He turned away from her, looking back out the window. "Be certain that I do not see your face.

ɛvɝ əɡɛn, kædzueɪn. jə meɪ ɡoʊ naʊ."

Ever again, Cadsuane. You may go now."

deɪzd, ʃi tɝnd - ən fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ, ʃi sɔ ə dip dɑɹknəs ɛməneɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ælθɹ, wɔɹpɪŋ ði ɛɹ ivən fɝðɝ. wən ʃi ɡlæns bæk, ɪt wɑz ɡɔn. wɪð ɡɹɪɾɪd tiθ, ʃi lɛft.

Dazed, she turned - and from the corner of her eye, she saw a deep darkness emanating from al'Thor, warping the air even further. When she glanced back, it was gone. With gritted teeth, she left.

"pɹipɛɹ jʊɹsɛlvz ən jəɹ ɑɹmiz," ælθɹ sɛd tə ðoʊz u ɹɪmeɪnd, vɔɪs ɛkoʊɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹum bɪhaɪnd. "aɪ ɪntɛn tə bi ɡɔn baɪ wiks ɛnd."

"Prepare yourselves and your armies," al'Thor said to those who remained, voice echoing in the room behind. "I intend to be gone by week's end."

kædzueɪn ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɝ hɛɾ ən lin əɡɛns ðə hɔlweɪ wɔl aʊtsaɪd, hɑɹt θʌmpɪŋ, hæn swɛɾɪŋ. bɪfɔɹ, ʃi hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ əɡɛnst ə stʌbɝn bʌt ɡʊd-hɑɹɾəd bɔɪ. sʌmwʌn hæd teɪkən ðət tʃaɪld ən ɹipleɪst ɪm wɪð ðɪs mæn, ə mæn mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən ɛni ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛt.

Cadsuane raised a hand to her head and leaned against the hallway wall outside, heart thumping, hand sweating. Before, she had been working against a stubborn but good-hearted boy. Someone had taken that child and replaced him with this man, a man more dangerous than any she had ever met.

deɪ baɪ deɪ, hi wɑz slɪpɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm.

Day by day, he was slipping away from them.

ən ət ðə moʊmənt, ʃi hædn ə blæstəd klu wʌt tə də əbaʊɾ ɪt.

And at the moment, she hadn't a blasted clue what to do about it.

tʃæptɝ twɛntifɔɹ

CHAPTER 24

eɪ nu kəmɪtmən ɪɡzɔstəd fɹəm deɪz ə hɑɹd tʃɹævəl, ɡɔɪn sæɾ ətɑp tʃælənʒ ɑn ə loʊ hɪl saʊθwɛst ə tɑɹ vəlɑn.

A New Commitment Exhausted from days of hard travel, Gawyn sat atop Challenge on a low hill southwest of Tar Valon.

ðɪs kʌntʃɹisaɪd ʃʊɾə bɪn ɡɹin wɪð spɹɪŋz ɝaɪvəl, bʌt ðə hɪlsaɪd bɪfɔɹ ɪm bɔɹ oʊnli skɹæɡli dɛd widz, sleɪn baɪ ðə wɪntɝ snoʊz. tʌfs ə ju ən blækwʊd poʊkt ʌp hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə bɹaʊn lændskeɪp. hi kaʊntəd mɔɹ ðən ə fju stænz ðət wɝ naʊ pɑpjəleɪɾəd oʊnli baɪ stʌmps. ə wɔɹ kæmp dɪvaʊɝd tʃɹiz laɪk hʌŋɡɹi wʊɡnɹlz, juzɪŋ əm fəɹ æɹoʊz, faɪɝz, bɪldɪŋz ən sidʒ ɪkwɪpmənt.

This countryside should have been green with spring's arrival, but the hillside before him bore only scraggly dead weeds, slain by the winter snows. Tufts of yew and blackwood poked up here and there, breaking the brown landscape. He counted more than a few stands that were now populated only by stumps. A war camp devoured trees like hungry woodgnarls, using them for arrows, fires, buildings and siege equipment.

ɡɔɪn jɔnd - hid pʊʃt hɑɹd θɹu ðə naɪt. bɹaɪnz wɔɹ kæmp wɑz wɛl dʌɡ ɪn hɪɹ, ən wɑz ə bʌsəl ə moʊʃən ən æktɪvəɾi. ən ɑɹmi ðɪs lɑɹdʒ spɔn ɔɹɡənaɪz keɪɑs ət bɛst. ə smɔl bæn ə maʊntəd kævəlɹi kəd tʃɹævəl laɪt, əz ɡɔɪnz jʌŋɡəlɪŋz hæd; ə fɔɹs laɪk ðət kəd ɡɹoʊ tə sɛvɹəl θaʊzən ən ɹɪmeɪn lin. ɛkspɝt hɔɹsmən, laɪk ðə sɑldəiənz, wɝ sɛd tə mænədʒ lɑɹdʒɝ bænz ə sɛvən əɹ eɪt θaʊzənd waɪl kipɪŋ ðɛɹ moʊbɪləɾi.

Gawyn yawned - he'd pushed hard through the night. Bryne's war camp was well dug in here, and was a bustle of motion and activity. An army this large spawned organized chaos at best. A small band of mounted cavalry could travel light, as Gawyn's Younglings had; a force like that could grow to several thousand and remain lean. Expert horsemen, like the Saldaeans, were said to manage larger bands of seven or eight thousand while keeping their mobility.

bʌɾ ə fɔɹs laɪk ðə wʌn bɪloʊ wɑz ə dɪfɹən bist ɪntaɪɝli. ɪt wɑz ən ɪnɔɹməs, spɹɔlɪŋ θɪŋ, ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ən ɪnɔɹməs bʌbəl wɪð ə smɔlɝ kæmp əɾ ɪts sɛntɝ; ðət pɹɑbli hɛl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. bɹaɪn ɔlsoʊ hæd fɔɹsɪz ɑkjəpaɪɪŋ ɔl ə ðə bɹɪdʒ taʊnz ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn, ɪfɛktɪvli kʌɾɪŋ ɔf ði aɪlən fɹəm ɡɹaʊn səplaɪ.

But a force like the one below was a different beast entirely. It was an enormous, sprawling thing, in the shape of an enormous bubble with a smaller camp at its center; that probably held the Aes Sedai. Bryne also had forces occupying all of the bridge towns on both sides of the River Erinin, effectively cutting off the island from ground supply.

ði ɑɹmi skwɑɾɪd nɪɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn laɪk ə spaɪɾɝ aɪɪŋ ə bʌɾɝflaɪ hʌvɝɪŋ dʒʌst aʊtsaɪɾ ʌv ɪts wɛb.

The army squatted near Tar Valon like a spider eyeing a butterfly hovering just outside of its web.

laɪnz ə tʃɹups ɹoʊɾ ɪn ən aʊt pətʃɹoʊlɪŋ, pɝtʃəsɪŋ fud, ɹʌnɪŋ mɛsədʒəz. dʌzənz əpɑn dʌzənz ə skwɑdz, səm maʊntəd, ʌðɝz wɔkɪŋ. laɪk biz livɪŋ ðə haɪv waɪl ʌðɝz swɔɹm bæk ɪn. ði istɝn saɪɾ ə ðə meɪn kæmp wɑz kɹaʊɾəd wɪð ə mɪʃmæʃ ə ʃæntiz ən tɛns, ðə nɔɹməl ɹɪfɹæf ə kæmp fɑloʊɝz ðət kəlɛktəɾ ɝaʊn ən ɑɹmi. nɪɹ baɪ, dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə meɪn wɔɹ-kæmp baʊndɝi, ə wʊɾən pælɪsɑd - pɝhæps fɪfti jɑɹdz əkɹɔs - ɹoʊz ɪn ə tɔl ɹɪŋ. pɹɑbli ə kəmæn poʊst.

Lines of troops rode in and out patrolling, purchasing food, running messages. Dozens upon dozens of squads, some mounted, others walking. Like bees leaving the hive while others swarmed back in. The eastern side of the main camp was crowded with a mishmash of shanties and tents, the normal riffraff of camp followers that collected around an army. Near by, just inside the main war-camp boundary, a wooden palisade - perhaps fifty yards across - rose in a tall ring. Probably a command post.

ɡɔɪn nu hi hæd bɪn sin baɪ bɹaɪnz skaʊts əz i əpɹoʊtʃt, jɛt nʌn hæd stɑp hɪm.

Gawyn knew he had been seen by Bryne's scouts as he approached, yet none had stopped him.

ðeɪ pɹɑbli wʊdn ənlɛs i tʃɹaɪd tə ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. ə sɪŋɡəl mæn - wɛɹɪŋ ə disənt ɡɹeɪ kloʊk ən tʃɹaʊzɝz, wɪð ə lɑsɪŋ ʃɝɾ ʌv waɪt - wɑzn ə mʌtʃ ɪntʃɹəst. hi kəd bi ə sɛl-sɔɹd, kʌmɪŋ tə æsk fəɹ ə pleɪs ɪn ðə ɹæŋks. hi kəd bi ə mɛsənʒɝ fɹəm ə loʊkəl lɔɹd, sɛn tə kəmpleɪn əbaʊɾ ə ɡɹup ə skaʊts. hi kəɾ ivən bi ə mɛmbɝ ə ði ɑɹmi. waɪl mɛni ʌv ðoʊz ɪn bɹaɪnz fɔɹs wɔɹ junəfɔɹmz, mɛni ʌðɝz dʒʌst wɔɹ ə sɪmpəl jɛloʊ bæn ɑn ðɛɹ koʊtslivz, nɑt jɛɾ eɪbəl tə peɪ fəɹ pɹɑpɝ ɪnsɪɡniə tə bi soʊn ɑn.

They probably wouldn't unless he tried to ride away. A single man - wearing a decent gray cloak and trousers, with a lacing shirt of white - wasn't of much interest. He could be a sell-sword, coming to ask for a place in the ranks. He could be a messenger from a local lord, sent to complain about a group of scouts. He could even be a member of the army. While many of those in Bryne's force wore uniforms, many others just wore a simple yellow band on their coatsleeves, not yet able to pay for proper insignia to be sewn on.

noʊ, ə sɪŋɡəl mæn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ði ɑɹmi wɑz nɑɾ ə deɪnʒɝ. ə sɪŋɡəl mæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɪt, haʊɛvɝ, wɑz kɑz fəɹ əlɑɹm. ə mæn kʌmɪŋ tə ðə kæmp kəd bi fɹɛnd, foʊ əɹ niðɝ. ə mæn u ɪnspɛktɪd ðə kæmp ðən ɹoʊɾ əweɪ wɑz ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli ə spaɪ. soʊ lɔŋ əz ɡɔɪn dɪdn liv bɪfɔɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪz ɪntɛntʃənz noʊn, bɹaɪnz aʊtʃɹaɪɾɝz wəd bi ənlaɪkli tə bɑðɝ hɪm.

No, a single man approaching the army was not a danger. A single man riding away from it, however, was cause for alarm. A man coming to the camp could be friend, foe or neither. A man who inspected the camp then rode away was almost certainly a spy. So long as Gawyn didn't leave before making his intentions known, Bryne's outriders would be unlikely to bother him.

laɪt, bʌɾ i kəd juz ə bɛd. hid spɛn ə ɹɛsləs tu naɪts, slipɪŋ oʊnli ə kʌpəl ʌv aʊɝz dʊɹɪŋ itʃ wʌn, ɹæpt ɪn ɪz kloʊk. hi fɛlt ɪɹəɾəbəl ən kɹæŋki, pɑɹʃəli dʒʌst ət hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə ɡoʊ tə ən ɪn, lɛst i bi tʃeɪs baɪ ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz. hi blɪŋk blɪɹi aɪz, ən spɝd tʃælənʒ daʊn ði ɪnklaɪn. hi wɑz kəmɪɾəd naʊ.

Light, but he could use a bed. He'd spent a restless two nights, sleeping only a couple of hours during each one, wrapped in his cloak. He felt irritable and cranky, partially just at himself for refusing to go to an inn, lest he be chased by the Younglings. He blinked bleary eyes, and spurred Challenge down the incline. He was committed now.

noʊ. hid bɪn kəmɪɾəd ðə moʊmən hid lɛf slit bɪhaɪn ɪn dɔɹlən. baɪ naʊ, ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz nu ʌv ðɛɹ liɾɝz bɪtʃɹeɪəl. slit wʊdn əlaʊ ðɛm tə weɪs taɪm sɝtʃɪŋ. hid tɛl əm wʌɾ i nu. ɡɔɪn wɪʃt i kəd kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf ðət ðeɪd bi sɝpɹaɪzd, bʌt hid ɹəsiv mɔɹ ðən wʌn fɹaʊn əɹ lʊk ə kənfjuʒən ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə weɪ hi spoʊk ʌv ɪleɪɾə ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

No. He'd been committed the moment he'd left Sleete behind in Dorlan. By now, the Younglings knew of their leader's betrayal. Sleete wouldn't allow them to waste time searching. He'd tell them what he knew. Gawyn wished he could convince himself that they'd be surprised, but he'd received more than one frown or look of confusion regarding the way he spoke of Elaida and the Aes Sedai.

ðə waɪt taʊɝ dɪdn dɪzɝv ɪz əlidʒəns, bʌt ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz - hi kəd nɛvɝ ɡoʊ bæk tə ðɛm, naʊ. ɪɾ ɪtʃt ət hɪm; ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɪz weɪvɝɪŋ hæd bɪn ɹɪvil tə ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup.

The White Tower didn't deserve his allegiance, but the Younglings - he could never go back to them, now. It itched at him; this was the first time his wavering had been revealed to a large group.

noʊbɑdi nu ðət hid hɛlp sɪuən ɪskeɪp, nɔɹ wɑz ɪt waɪdspɹɛd nɑlədʒ ðət hid dælid wɪð ɛɡwin.

Nobody knew that he'd helped Siuan escape, nor was it widespread knowledge that he'd dallied with Egwene.

jɛt livɪŋ hæd bɪn ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə du. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn mʌnθs, hɪz ækʃənz mætʃt ɪz hɑɹt. seɪvɪŋ ɛɡwin. ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ i kəd bɪliv ɪn.

Yet leaving had been the right thing to do. For the first time in months, his actions matched his heart. Saving Egwene. That was something he could believe in.

hi əpɹoʊtʃt ði aʊtskɝts ə kæmp, kipɪŋ ɪz feɪs ɪmpæsɪv. hi heɪɾəd ði aɪdiə ʌv wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz i hæd heɪɾəd əbændənɪŋ ɪz mɛn. ðiz ɹɛbəlz wɝ noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ɪleɪɾə. ðeɪ wɝ ðə wʌnz u hæd pɹɑpt ɛɡwin ʌp əz ən æmɪɝlɪn, əz ə tɑɹɡət.

He approached the outskirts of camp, keeping his face impassive. He hated the idea of working with the rebel Aes Sedai almost as much as he had hated abandoning his men. These rebels were no better than Elaida. They were the ones who had propped Egwene up as an Amyrlin, as a target.

ɛɡwin! ə mɪɹ æksɛptɪd. ə pɔn. ɪf ðeɪ feɪld ɪn ðɛɹ bɪd fəɹ ðə taʊɝ, ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɪskeɪp pʌnɪʃmənt. ɛɡwin wəd bi ɛksəkjuɾəd.

Egwene! A mere Accepted. A pawn. If they failed in their bid for the Tower, they themselves might be able to escape punishment. Egwene would be executed.

əl ɡɛɾ ɪn, ɡɔɪn θɔt. əl seɪv əɹ sʌmhaʊ. ðən əl tɔk səm sɛns ɪndə hɝ ən bɹɪŋ əɹ əweɪ fɹəm ɔl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. pɝhæps ivən tɔk sɛns ɪndə bɹaɪn. wi kən ɔl ɡɛt bæk tə ændɝ, tə hɛlp ɪleɪn.

I'll get in, Gawyn thought. I'll save her somehow. Then I'll talk some sense into her and bring her away from all of the Aes Sedai. Perhaps even talk sense into Bryne. We can all get back to Andor, to help Elayne.

hi ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd wɪð ɹɪnud dɪtɝməneɪʃən, bænɪʃɪŋ səm ə hɪz ɪɡzɔstʃən. tə ɹitʃ ðə kəmæn poʊst, hi hæd tə ɹaɪd θɹu ðə kæmp fɑloʊɝz, hu aʊtnʌmbɝd ði æktʃəwəl tʃɹups. kʊks tə fɪks ðə fud. wɪmən tə sɝv ðə fuɾ ən wɑʃ ðə sɔɪl dɪʃəz. wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz tə kæɹi ðə fud.

He rode forward with renewed determination, banishing some of his exhaustion. To reach the command post, he had to ride through the camp followers, who outnumbered the actual troops. Cooks to fix the food. Women to serve the food and wash the soiled dishes. Wagon drivers to carry the food.

wilɹaɪts tə fɪks ðə wæɡənz ðət kæɹid ðə fud. blæksmɪθs tə meɪk hɔɹsʃuz fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz ðət pʊl ðə wæɡənz ðət kæɹid ðə fud. mɝtʃəns tə baɪ ðə fud, ən kɔɹɾɝmæstɝz tə ɔɹɡənaɪz ɪt. lɛs ɹɛpjəɾəbəl mɝtʃəns u sɔt tə pɹɑfəɾ ɔf ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ən ðɛɹ bæɾəl peɪ, ən wɪmən u sɔt tə də ðə seɪm. bɔɪz tə ɹʌn mɛsədʒəz, hoʊpɪŋ tə sʌmdeɪ kæɹi ə sɔɹd ðɛmsɛlvz.

Wheelwrights to fix the wagons that carried the food. Blacksmiths to make horseshoes for the horses that pulled the wagons that carried the food. Merchants to buy the food, and quartermasters to organize it. Less reputable merchants who sought to profit off of the soldiers and their battle pay, and women who sought to do the same. Boys to run messages, hoping to someday carry a sword themselves.

ɪt wɑz ə kəmplit mɛs. ə hæf-ʃænti kənɡlɑmɝeɪʃən ə tɛns ən ʃæks, itʃ ʌv ə dɪfɹən hju, dɪzaɪn ən steɪɾ ə dɪsɹɪpɛɹ. ivən ə keɪpəbəl dʒɛnɝəl laɪk bɹaɪn kəɾ ɪmpoʊz oʊnli soʊ mʌtʃ ɔɹɾɝ ɑn kæmp fɑloʊɝz. hɪz mɛn wəd kip ðə pis, mɔɹ əɹ lɛs, bʌt ðeɪ kʊdn fɔɹs fɑloʊɝz tə kip mɪlətɛɹi dɪsəplən.

It was a complete mess. A half-shanty conglomeration of tents and shacks, each of a different hue, design and state of disrepair. Even a capable general like Bryne could impose only so much order on camp followers. His men would keep the peace, more or less, but they couldn't force followers to keep military discipline.

ɡɔɪn pæs θɹu ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪɾ ɔl, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðoʊz u kɔl tə hɪm ɔfɝɪŋ tə ʃaɪn ɪz sɔɹɾ əɹ sɛl ɪm ə switbʌn. ðə pɹaɪsəz wəd bi loʊ - ðɪs wɑz ə pleɪs ðət fɛɾ ɔf ə soʊlʒɝz -  bʌt wɪð ɪz wɔɹhɔɹs ən faɪnɝ kloʊðɪŋ, hid bi mɑɹkt əz ən ɔfəsɝ. ɪf i bɑt fɹəm wʌn, ði ʌðɝz wəd smɛl kɔɪn, ən i kəɾ ɛn ʌp sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɔl u hoʊp tə sɛl tə hɪm.

Gawyn passed through the middle of it all, ignoring those who called to him offering to shine his sword or sell him a sweetbun. The prices would be low - this was a place that fed off of soldiers -  but with his warhorse and finer clothing, he'd be marked as an officer. If he bought from one, the others would smell coin, and he could end up surrounded by all who hoped to sell to him.

hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðə kɔlz, aɪz fɔɹwɝd, təwɔɹd ði ɑɹmi ɪtsɛlf əhɛd. ɪts tɛns wɝ dʒɛnɝəli ɔɹɡənaɪzd ɪn nit ɹoʊz, ɡɹup baɪ skwɑɾ ən bænɝ, ðoʊ səmtaɪmz ɪn smɔlɝ klʌstɝz. ɡɔɪn cʊɾə ɡɛs ðə leɪaʊt wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ɪt. bɹaɪn laɪkt ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ bɪliv stʃɹɔŋli ɪn dɛləɡeɪʃən. bɹaɪn wəɾ əlaʊ ɔfəsɝz tə ɹʌn ðɛɹ kæmps əz ðeɪ wɪʃt, ən ðət lɛd tə ə sɛtʌp ðət wɑz lɛs junəfɔɹm, jɛt wɑz fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ət ɹʌnɪŋ ɪtsɛlf.

He ignored the calls, eyes forward, toward the army itself ahead. Its tents were generally organized in neat rows, grouped by squad and banner, though sometimes in smaller clusters. Gawyn could have guessed the layout without seeing it. Bryne liked organization, but also believed strongly in delegation. Bryne would allow officers to run their camps as they wished, and that led to a setup that was less uniform, yet was far better at running itself.

hi hɛɾəd dɝɛkli fəɹ ðə pælɪsɑd. ðə kæmp fɑloʊɝz ɝaʊn ɪm wɝn izi tə ɪɡnɔɹ, haʊɛvɝ. ðɛɹ kɔlz tə hɪm lɪŋɡɝɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ, təɡɛðɝ wɪð ðə sɛns ə kʊkɪŋ, pɹaɪviz, hɔɹsəz ən tʃip pɝfjum. ðə kæmp wɑzn əz kɹaʊɾəd əz ə sɪɾi, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ wɑzn əz wɛl meɪnteɪnd.

He headed directly for the palisade. The camp followers around him weren't easy to ignore, however. Their calls to him lingered in the air, together with the scents of cooking, privies, horses and cheap perfume. The camp wasn't as crowded as a city, but it also wasn't as well maintained.

swɛt mɪkst wɪð bɝnɪŋ kʊk faɪɝz mɪkst wɪð stæɡnənt wɔɾɝ mɪkst wɪð ənwɑʃt bɑɾiz. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə hoʊld ə hæŋkɝtʃɪf tə hɪz feɪs, ðoʊ hi ɹɪfɹeɪnd. ɪt wəd meɪk ɪm lʊk laɪk ə spɔɪl noʊbəl, tɝnɪŋ ɪz noʊz ʌp ət ðə kɑmən pipəl.

Sweat mixed with burning cook fires mixed with stagnant water mixed with unwashed bodies. It made him want to hold a handkerchief to his face, though he refrained. It would make him look like a spoiled noble, turning his nose up at the common people.

ðə stɪŋk, ðə kənfjuʒən ən ðə jɛlz dɪdn hɛlp ɪz muɾ ɛni. hi hæd tə ɡɹɪɾ ɪz tiθ tə kip hɪmsɛlf fɹəm kɝsɪŋ əɾ itʃ hɔkɝ. ə fɪɡjɝ stʌmbəld ɑntu ðə pæθweɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm - hi ɹeɪn ɪn. ðə wʊmən wɔɹ ə bɹaʊn skɝɾ ən ə waɪt blaʊs, hɝ hænz ɡɹaɪmi. "aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ," ɡɔɪn snæpt. hɪz mʌðɝ wʊɾə bɪn aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ tə hɪɹ ɪm spikɪŋ wɪð sətʃ æŋɡɝ. wɛl, hɪz mʌðɝ wɑz dɛd naʊ, baɪ ælθɹz hænd.

The stink, the confusion and the yells didn't help his mood any. He had to grit his teeth to keep himself from cursing at each hawker. A figure stumbled onto the pathway in front of him - he reined in. The woman wore a brown skirt and a white blouse, her hands grimy. "Out of the way," Gawyn snapped. His mother would have been outraged to hear him speaking with such anger. Well, his mother was dead now, by al'Thor's hand.

ðə wʊmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm lʊkt ʌp ən ɹæn bæk aʊɾ ə ðə pæθweɪ. ʃi hæd laɪt hɛɹ taɪɾ ɪn ə jɛloʊ kɝtʃəf ən ə feɪnli plʌmp bɑɾi. ɡɔɪn kɑt dʒʌst ə ɡlɪmps ə hɝ feɪs əz ʃi tɝnd.

The woman in front of him looked up and ran back out of the pathway. She had light hair tied in a yellow kerchief and a faintly plump body. Gawyn caught just a glimpse of her face as she turned.

ɡɔɪn fɹoʊz. ðət wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs! ɪt wɑz ʌnmɪsteɪkəbəl. hi sæt, ʃɑkt, əz ðə wʊmən pʊld əɹ kɝtʃəf daʊn ən hɝiɾ əweɪ.

Gawyn froze. That was an Aes Sedai face! It was unmistakable. He sat, shocked, as the woman pulled her kerchief down and hurried away.

"weɪt!" hi kɔld, tɝnɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs. bʌt ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt stɑp. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm əz i sɔ ðə wʊmən dʒɔɪn ə laɪn ʌv wɑʃwɪmən wɝkɪŋ bɪtwin sɛvɹəl wʊɾən tʃɹɔfs ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ. ɪf ʃi wɑz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ə kɑmən wʊmən, ðən ʃi laɪkli hæɾ əɹ oʊn blæstəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹizənz, ən ʃi wʊdn əpɹiʃieɪɾ ɪm ɪkspoʊzɪŋ hɝ. vɛɹi wɛl. ɡɔɪn fɔɹs daʊn ɪz ənɔɪəns. ɛɡwin. hi hæd tə foʊkəs ɑn ɛɡwin.

"Wait!" he called, turning his horse. But the woman did not stop. He hesitated, lowering his arm as he saw the woman join a line of washwomen working between several wooden troughs a short distance away. If she was pretending to be a common woman, then she likely had her own blasted Aes Sedai reasons, and she wouldn't appreciate him exposing her. Very well. Gawyn forced down his annoyance. Egwene. He had to focus on Egwene.

wən i ɹitʃt ðə kəmæn pælɪsɑd, ði ɛɹ ɪmpɹuv mɛʒɝəbli. ə kwɔɹtɛɾ ə soʊlʒɝz stʊɾ ɑn ɡɑɹd, hælbɝdz hɛld ət ðɛɹ saɪdz, stil kæps ɡlimɪŋ ən mætʃt baɪ bɹɛstpleɪts ɛmbleɪzənd wɪð bɹaɪnz θɹi stɑɹz. ə bænɝ bɛɹɪŋ ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn flæp bɪsaɪd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ.

When he reached the command palisade, the air improved measurably. A quartet of soldiers stood on guard, halberds held at their sides, steel caps gleaming and matched by breastplates emblazoned with Bryne's three stars. A banner bearing the flame of Tar Valon flapped beside the gateway.

"ɹəkɹut?" æskt wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz əz ɡɔɪn ɹoʊɾ ʌp. ðə hɛvisɛt mæn bɔɹ ə ɹɛd stʃɹaɪp ɑn ɪz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ, mɑɹkɪŋ ɪm əz ə wɑtʃ sɑɹdʒənt. hi kæɹiɾ ə sɔɹɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə hælbɹd. hɪz bɹɛstpleɪt bɛɹli fɪɾ ɪz ɡɝθ, ən ɪz tʃɪn bɹɪsəld wɪð ɹɛd hɛɹz. "jul əv tə mit wɪð kæptən ɑldən," ðə mæn sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt. "bɪɡ blu tɛn əbaʊɾ ə kɔɹɾɝ ə ðə weɪ ɝaʊn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə kæmp. juv ɡɑt jəɹ oʊn hɔɹs ən sɔɹd; ðæɾəl ɡɛt jə ɡʊd peɪ." ðə mæn pɔɪntəd təwɔɹɾ ə dɪstən pɔɪn ɪn ðə meɪn bɑɾi ʌv ði ɑɹmi, aʊtsaɪd ðə pælɪsɑd. ðət wʊdn du. hi kəd si bɹaɪnz bænɝ flaɪɪŋ ɪnsaɪd.

"Recruit?" asked one of the soldiers as Gawyn rode up. The heavyset man bore a red stripe on his left shoulder, marking him as a watch sergeant. He carried a sword instead of a halberd. His breastplate barely fit his girth, and his chin bristled with red hairs. "You'll have to meet with Captain Aldan," the man said with a grunt. "Big blue tent about a quarter of the way around the outside of the camp. You've got your own horse and sword; that'll get you good pay." The man pointed toward a distant point in the main body of the army, outside the palisade. That wouldn't do. He could see Bryne's banner flying inside.

"aɪm nɑɾ ə ɹəkɹut," ɡɔɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tʃælənʒ tə ɡɛɾ ə bɛɾɝ lʊk ət ðə mɛn. "maɪ neɪm ɪz ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd. aɪ nid tə spik wɪð ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ɪmiɾiətli əbaʊɾ ə mæɾɝ ə səm ɝdʒənsi."

"I'm not a recruit," Gawyn said, turning Challenge to get a better look at the men. "My name is Gawyn Trakand. I need to speak with Gareth Bryne immediately about a matter of some urgency."

ðə soʊlʒɝ ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. ðən i tʃʌkəl tə hɪmsɛlf.

The soldier raised an eyebrow. Then he chuckled to himself.

"ju doʊn bɪliv mi," ɡɔɪn sɛd flætli.

"You don't believe me," Gawyn said flatly.

"ju ʃəd ɡoʊ spik tə kæptən ɑldən," ðə mæn sɛd læzəli, pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɪstən tɛn əɡɛn.

"You should go speak to Captain Aldan," the man said lazily, pointing toward the distant tent again.

ɡɔɪn tʊk ə kɑmɪŋ bɹɛθ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs daʊn ɪz ɪɹɪteɪʃən. "ɪf jud dʒʌst sɛn fəɹ bɹaɪn, jud faɪn ðət - "

Gawyn took a calming breath, trying to force down his irritation. "If you'd just send for Bryne, you'd find that - "

"ɑɹ jə gɑnə bi tʃɹʌbəl?" ðə soʊlʒɝ æskt, pʌfɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp. ði ʌðɝ mɛn ɹɛɾid ðɛɹ hælbɝdz.

"Are you going to be trouble?" the soldier asked, puffing himself up. The other men readied their halberds.

"noʊ tʃɹʌbəl," ɡɔɪn sɛɾ ivənli. "aɪ dʒʌs nid - "

"No trouble," Gawyn said evenly. "I just need - "

"ɪf jəɹ gɑnə bi ɪn əɹ kæmp," ðə soʊlʒɝ ɪntɝʌptɪd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, "jɔɹ gɑnə hæv tə lɝn haʊ tə də wʌt jəɹ toʊld."

"If you're going to be in our camp," the soldier interrupted, stepping forward, "you're going to have to learn how to do what you're told."

ɡɔɪn mɛt ðə mænz aɪz. "vɛɹi wɛl. wi kən də ɪt ðɪs weɪ. ɪɾəl pɹɑbli bi fæstɝ ɛniweɪ."

Gawyn met the man's eyes. "Very well. We can do it this way. It will probably be faster anyway."

ðə sɑɹdʒən leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd.

The sergeant laid a hand on his sword.

ɡɔɪn kɪkt ɪz fit fɹi ʌv ðə stɝəps ən pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl. ɪt wəd bi tu hɑɹd tə kip fɹəm kɪlɪŋ ðə mæn fɹəm hɔɹsbæk. hi slɪɾ ɪz bleɪd fɹi əz ɪz fit hɪt ðə mʌɾi ɡɹaʊnd, ðə ʃiθ ɹæspɪŋ laɪk ən ɪnheɪl bɹɛθ. ɡɔɪn fɛl ɪndə oʊk ʃeɪks ɪts bɹæntʃəz, ə fɔɹm ðət wildɪd nɑnliθəl bloʊz, ɔfən juz baɪ mæstɝz fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ðɛɹ stuɾənts. ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ vɛɹi ɪfɛktɪv əɡɛnst ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup ɔl juzɪŋ dɪfɹənt wɛpənz.

Gawyn kicked his feet free of the stirrups and pushed himself out of the saddle. It would be too hard to keep from killing the man from horseback. He slid his blade free as his feet hit the muddy ground, the sheath rasping like an inhaled breath. Gawyn fell into Oak Shakes Its Branches, a form that wielded nonlethal blows, often used by masters for training their students. It was also very effective against a large group all using different weapons.

bɪfɔɹ ðə sɑɹdʒən hæɾ ɪz sɔɹd fɹi, ɡɔɪn slæmd ɪndə hɪm, ɹæmɪŋ ən ɛlboʊ ɪndə hɪz ɡʌt dʒʌs bɪniθ ðə pʊɹli fɪɾɪŋ bɹɛstpleɪt. ðə mæn ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən bɛnt, ðən ɡɔɪn nɑkt ɪm ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hɛd wɪð ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd - ðə mæn ʃʊɾə noʊn bɛɾɝ ðən tə wɛɹ ɪz kæp əskju laɪk ðæt. ðən ɡɔɪn fɛl ɪndə pɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪlk tə dil wɪð ðə fɝs hælbɝɾiɝ. əz ənʌðɝ ə ðə mɛn skɹim fəɹ hɛlp, ɡɔɪnz bleɪd slæʃt əkɹɔs ðə fɝs hælbɝɾiɝz bɹɛstpleɪt wɪð ə ɹɪŋɪŋ saʊnd, fɔɹsɪŋ ðə mæn bæk. ɡɔɪn fɪnɪʃt baɪ swipɪŋ ðə mænz fit fɹəm ʌndɝ hɪm, ðən fɛl ɪndə twɪstɪŋ ðə wɪn tə blɑk ə pɛɹ ə bloʊz fɹəm ði ʌðɝ tu mɛn.

Before the sergeant had his sword free, Gawyn slammed into him, ramming an elbow into his gut just beneath the poorly fitting breastplate. The man grunted and bent, then Gawyn knocked him on the side of the head with the hilt of his sword - the man should have known better than to wear his cap askew like that. Then Gawyn fell into Parting the Silk to deal with the first halberdier. As another of the men screamed for help, Gawyn's blade slashed across the first halberdier's breastplate with a ringing sound, forcing the man back. Gawyn finished by sweeping the man's feet from under him, then fell into Twisting the Wind to block a pair of blows from the other two men.

ɪt wɑz ənfɔɹtʃənət, bʌɾ i hæd tə ɹɪzɔɹt tə stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ðə θaɪz ə ðə tu stændɪŋ hælbɝdɪɝz. hiɾ əv pɹəfɝd tə əvɔɪd wundɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt faɪts - ivən wʌn sətʃ əz ðɪs, əɡɛns fɑɹ lɛs skɪld əpoʊnəns - bɪkeɪm ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl ðə lɔŋɡɝ ðeɪ læstəd. wʌn hæd tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə bæɾəlfild kwɪkli ən saʊnli, ən ðət mɛn dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə tu soʊlʒɝz - klʌtʃɪŋ ðɛɹ bliɾɪŋ θaɪz. ðə sɑɹdʒənt wɑz aʊt koʊl fɹəm ðə ɹæp tə ðə hɛd, bʌt ðə fɝs hælbɝɾiɝ wɑz ɹaɪzɪŋ ʃɑkəli. ɡɔɪn kɪk ðə mænz hælbɹɾ əsaɪd, ðən plæntəɾ ə buɾ ɪn ɪz feɪs, nɑkɪŋ ɪm bæk ən blʌɾiɪŋ ɪz noʊz.

It was unfortunate, but he had to resort to striking the thighs of the two standing halberdiers. He'd have preferred to avoid wounding them, but fights - even one such as this, against far less skilled opponents - became unpredictable the longer they lasted. One had to control the battlefield quickly and soundly, and that meant dropping the two soldiers - clutching their bleeding thighs. The sergeant was out cold from the rap to the head, but the first halberdier was rising shakily. Gawyn kicked the man's halberd aside, then planted a boot in his face, knocking him back and bloodying his nose.

tʃælənʒ wɪnid fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, snɔɹɾɪŋ ən stæmpɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə wɔɹhɔɹs sɛnst ə faɪt, bʌt wɑz wɛl tʃɹeɪnd. hi nu ðət wən ɪz ɹeɪnz wɝ dʒɹɑpt, hi wɑz tə ɹɪmeɪn stɪl. ɡɔɪn waɪpt ɪz bleɪɾ ɑn ɪz tʃɹaʊzɝ lɛɡ, ðən slɪɾ ɪt bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ, ðə wundəd soʊlʒɝz ɡɹoʊnɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi pæɾəd tʃælənʒ ɑn ðə noʊz ən tʊk ʌp ðə ɹeɪnz əɡɛn. bɪhaɪnd ɡɔɪn, nɪɹbaɪ kæmp fɑloʊɝz bækt əweɪ, ðən ɹæn. ə ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə pælɪsɑɾ əpɹoʊtʃt wɪð baʊz dʒɹɔn. ðət wɑz nɑt ɡʊd. ɡɔɪn tɝn tə feɪs ðɛm, pʊlɪŋ ɪz stɪl-ʃið sɔɹd fɹi fɹəm ɪz bɛlt ən tɔsɪŋ ɪt tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə mɛn.

Challenge whinnied from behind, snorting and stamping the ground. The warhorse sensed a fight, but was well trained. He knew that when his reins were dropped, he was to remain still. Gawyn wiped his blade on his trouser leg, then slid it back into its sheath, the wounded soldiers groaning on the ground. He patted Challenge on the nose and took up the reins again. Behind Gawyn, nearby camp followers backed away, then ran. A group of soldiers from inside the palisade approached with bows drawn. That was not good. Gawyn turned to face them, pulling his still-sheathed sword free from his belt and tossing it to the ground in front of the men.

"aɪ æm ənɑɹmd," hi sɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə saʊnz ə ðə wundəd. "ænd nʌn ə ðiz fɔɹ wɪl daɪ ðɪs deɪ. ɡoʊ ən tɛl jəɹ dʒɛnɝəl ðəɾ ə loʊn bleɪdmæstɝ dʒʌs fɛld ə skwɑɾ ə hɪz ɡɑɹdz ɪn ʌndɝ tɛn hɑɹtbits. ɪm ən oʊl stuɾənt ə hɪz. hɪl wɑnə si mi."

"I am unarmed," he said over the sounds of the wounded. "And none of these four will die this day. Go and tell your general that a lone blademaster just felled a squad of his guards in under ten heartbeats. I'm an old student of his. He'll want to see me."

wʌn ə ðə mɛn skɹæmbəl fɔɹwɝd tə teɪk ɡɔɪnz fɔlən sɔɹd waɪl ənʌðɝ sɪɡnəl tə ə ɹʌnɝ. ði ʌðɝz kɛp ðɛɹ baʊz ɹeɪzd. wʌn ə ðə fɔlən hælbɝdɪɝz bɪɡæn tə kɹɔl əweɪ. ɡɔɪn tɝn tʃælənʒ əɾ ən æŋɡəl, meɪkɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə dʌk bɪhaɪn ðə hɔɹs ɪf ðə soʊlʒɝz muv tə dʒɹɔ.

One of the men scrambled forward to take Gawyn's fallen sword while another signaled to a runner. The others kept their bows raised. One of the fallen halberdiers began to crawl away. Gawyn turned Challenge at an angle, making ready to duck behind the horse if the soldiers moved to draw.

hid mʌtʃ pɹəfɝ ɪt nɑt kʌm tə ðæt, bʌɾ ə ðə tu ʌv ðɛm, tʃælənʒ wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ laɪkli tə sɝvaɪv ə fju ʃɔɹtboʊ ʃæfs ðən ɡɔɪn.

He'd much prefer it not come to that, but of the two of them, Challenge was far more likely to survive a few shortbow shafts than Gawyn.

sɛvɹəl ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹɪskt kʌmɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə hɛlp ðɛɹ fɔlən fɹɛnz. ðə hɛvisɛt wɑtʃ sɑɹdʒənt wɑz stɝɪŋ, ən i sæɾ ʌp, kɝsɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. ɡɔɪn meɪd noʊ θɹɛɾənɪŋ moʊʃənz.

Several of the soldiers risked coming forward to help their fallen friends. The heavyset watch sergeant was stirring, and he sat up, cursing under his breath. Gawyn made no threatening motions.

pɝhæps ɪt hæd bɪn ə mɪsteɪk tə faɪt ðə mɛn, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi weɪstəd tu mʌtʃ taɪm. ɛɡwin kəd bi dɛd baɪ naʊ! wən ə mæn laɪk ðət sɑɹdʒən tʃɹaɪd tə əsɝɾ ɪz əθɔɹəɾi, jə ɹɪli oʊnli hæd tu ɑpʃənz. jə kəd tɔk jəɹ weɪ ʌp θɹu ðə ɹæŋks ə ðə bjʊɹɑkɹəsi, kənvɪnsɪŋ itʃ soʊlʒɝ itʃ stɛp ə ðə weɪ ðət jə wɝ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. əɹ jə kəd meɪk ə dɪstɝbəns. ðə sɛkənd wɑz fæstɝ, ən ðə kæmp ɑbviəsli hæɾ ɪnʌf ɛɛs sədaɪ səpɔɹt tə hil ə fju ɪnʒɝd soʊlʒɝz.

Perhaps it had been a mistake to fight the men, but he had already wasted too much time. Egwene could be dead by now! When a man like that sergeant tried to assert his authority, you really only had two options. You could talk your way up through the ranks of the bureaucracy, convincing each soldier each step of the way that you were important. Or you could make a disturbance. The second was faster, and the camp obviously had enough Aes Sedai support to Heal a few injured soldiers.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ə smɔl ɡɹup ə mɛn stʃɹoʊɾ aʊt fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə pælɪsɑd. ðɛɹ junəfɔɹmz wɝ ʃɑɹp, ðɛɹ pɑstʃɝz deɪnʒɝəs, ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɔɹn. ət ðɛɹ hɛd keɪm ə skwɛɹ-feɪs mæn wɪð ɡɹeɪɪŋ tɛmpəlz ən ə stʃɹɔŋ, stɑki bɪld. ɡɔɪn smaɪld. bɹaɪn hɪmsɛlf. ðə ɡæmbəl hæd wɝkt.

Eventually, a small group of men strode out from inside the palisade. Their uniforms were sharp, their postures dangerous, their faces worn. At their head came a square-faced man with graying temples and a strong, stocky build. Gawyn smiled. Bryne himself. The gamble had worked.

ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl sɝveɪd ɡɔɪn, ðən muvd ɑn tə ə kwɪk ɪnspɛkʃən ə hɪz fɔlən soʊlʒɝz.

The Captain-General surveyed Gawyn, then moved on to a quick inspection of his fallen soldiers.

ət læst, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "stæn daʊn," hi sɛd tə hɪz mɛn. "sɑɹdʒən kɔɹdz."

At last, he shook his head. "Stand down," he said to his men. "Sergeant Cords."

ðə stɑki sɑɹdʒən stʊɾ ʌp. "sɝ!"

The stocky sergeant stood up. "Sir!"

bɹaɪn ɡlæns bæk ət ɡɔɪn. "nɛks taɪm ə mæn kʌmz tə ðə ɡeɪt kleɪmɪŋ tə bi noʊbɪləɾi ən æskɪŋ fəɹ mi, sɛn fəɹ ən ɔfəsɝ. ɪmiɾiətli. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ ɪf ðə mæn əz tu mʌnθs ə skɹʌfi bɪɹɾ ən ɹiks ə tʃip eɪl. ʌndɝstʊd?"

Bryne glanced back at Gawyn. "Next time a man comes to the gate claiming to be nobility and asking for me, send for an officer. Immediately. I don't care if the man has two months of scruffy beard and reeks of cheap ale. Understood?"

"jɛs, sɝ," ðə sɑɹdʒən sɛd, blʌʃɪŋ. "ʌndɝstʊd, sɝ."

"Yes, sir," the sergeant said, blushing. "Understood, sir."

"si jəɹ mɛn tə ði ɪnfɝmɝi, sɑɹdʒənt," bɹaɪn sɛd, stɪl lʊkɪŋ ət ɡɔɪn. "ju, kʌm wɪð mi."

"See your men to the infirmary, Sergeant," Bryne said, still looking at Gawyn. "You, come with me."

ɡɔɪn klɛntʃt ɪz dʒɔ. hi hædn ɹəsiv sətʃ ən ədʒɹɛs fɹəm ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn sɪns bɪfɔɹ hid stɑɹɾəd ʃeɪvɪŋ. stɪl, hi kʊdn ɹɪli ɪkspɛk ðə mæn tə bi plizd. dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə pælɪsɑd, ɡɔɪn spɑɾəd ə jʌŋ bɔɪ hu wɑz laɪkli ə steɪbəlɪhæn əɹ mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪ. hi hændəd tʃælənʒ tə ðə waɪd-aɪd juθ, ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ ɪm tə si ðə hɔɹs kɛɹd fɔɹ. ðən ɡɔɪn ɹitʃɹivd ɪz sɔɹd fɹəm ðə mæn hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ən hɝiɾ æftɝ bɹaɪn.

Gawyn clenched his jaw. He hadn't received such an address from Gareth Bryne since before he'd started shaving. Still, he couldn't really expect the man to be pleased. Just inside the palisade, Gawyn spotted a young boy who was likely a stablehand or messenger boy. He handed Challenge to the wide-eyed youth, instructing him to see the horse cared for. Then Gawyn retrieved his sword from the man holding it and hurried after Bryne.

"ɡɛɹɪθ," ɡɔɪn sɛd, kætʃɪŋ ʌp, "aɪ - "

"Gareth," Gawyn said, catching up, "I - "

"hoʊl jəɹ tʌŋ, jʌŋ mæn," bɹaɪn sɛd, nɑt tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. "aɪ hævən dɪsaɪɾɪd wʌɾ aɪm gɑnə də wɪð ju."

"Hold your tongue, young man," Bryne said, not turning toward him. "I haven't decided what I'm going to do with you."

ɡɔɪn snæpt ɪz maʊθ kloʊzd. ðət wɑz ənkɔl fɔɹ! ɡɔɪn wɑz stɪl bɹʌðɝ tə ðə ɹaɪtfəl kwin ʌv ændɝ, ən wəd bi fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd ʃəɾ ɪleɪn teɪk ən hoʊl ðə θɹoʊn!

Gawyn snapped his mouth closed. That was uncalled for! Gawyn was still brother to the rightful Queen of Andor, and would be First Prince of the Sword should Elayne take and hold the throne!

bɹaɪn ʃəd ʃoʊ hɪm ɹɪspɛkt.

Bryne should show him respect.

bʌt bɹaɪn kəd bi stʌbɝn əz ə bɔɹ. ɡɔɪn hɛld ɪz tʌŋ. ðeɪ ɹitʃt ə tɔl, pik tɛnt wɪð tu ɡɑɹdz ət ðə fɹʌnt. bɹaɪn dʌkt ɪnsaɪɾ ən ɡɔɪn fɑloʊd. ði ɪnsaɪd wɑz niɾ ən klin, mɔɹ soʊ ðən ɡɔɪn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. ðə dɛsk wɑz stækt wɪð ɹoʊl mæps ən ɔɹɾɝli ʃits ə peɪpɝ, ən ðə pæləts ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ wɝ ɹoʊl kɛɹfəli, blæŋkəts foʊldəd wɪð ʃɑɹp æŋɡəlz. bɹaɪn wɑz ɑbviəsli ɹilaɪɪŋ ɑn sʌmwʌn mətɪkjələs tə taɪɾi ʌp fəɹ hɪm.

But Bryne could be stubborn as a boar. Gawyn held his tongue. They reached a tall, peaked tent with two guards at the front. Bryne ducked inside and Gawyn followed. The inside was neat and clean, more so than Gawyn had expected. The desk was stacked with rolled maps and orderly sheets of paper, and the pallets in the corner were rolled carefully, blankets folded with sharp angles. Bryne was obviously relying on someone meticulous to tidy up for him.

bɹaɪn klæspt ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, bɹɛstpleɪt ɹəflɛktɪŋ ɡɔɪnz feɪs əz i tɝn ɝaʊnd.

Bryne clasped his hands behind his back, breastplate reflecting Gawyn's face as he turned around.

"ɔl ɹaɪt. ɪkspleɪn wʌt jəɹ duɪŋ hɪɹ."

"All right. Explain what you're doing here."

ɡɔɪn dʒɹu hɪmsɛlf ʌp. "dʒɛnɝəl," hi sɛd, "aɪ θɪŋk jə mɪsteɪk jɝsɛlf. ɪm noʊ lɔŋɡɝ jəɹ stuɾənt."

Gawyn drew himself up. "General," he said, "I think you mistake yourself. I'm no longer your student."

"aɪ noʊ," bɹaɪn sɛd kɝtli. "ðə bɔɪ aɪ tʃɹeɪnd wəd nɛvɝ əv pʊld ə tʃaɪldɪʃ stʌn laɪk ðət wʌn tə ɡɛt maɪ ətɛnʃən."

"I know," Bryne said curtly. "The boy I trained would never have pulled a childish stunt like that one to get my attention."

"ðə wɑtʃ sɑɹdʒənt wɑz bəlɪdʒɝənt, ən aɪ hæd noʊ peɪʃəns fəɹ ðə pɑstʃɝɪŋ ʌv ə ful. ðɪs sim ðə bɛst weɪ."

"The watch sergeant was belligerent, and I had no patience for the posturing of a fool. This seemed the best way."

"ðə bɛst weɪ tə wʌt?" bɹaɪn æskt. "aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ mi?"

"The best way to what?" Bryne asked. "Outrage me?"

"lʊk," ɡɔɪn sɛd, "pɝhæps aɪ wɑz heɪsti, bʌɾ aɪ hæv ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt tæsk. jə nid tə lɪsən tə mi."

"Look," Gawyn said, "perhaps I was hasty, but I have an important task. You need to listen to me."

"æn ɪf aɪ doʊnt?" bɹaɪn æskt. "ɪf aɪ ɪnstɛd θɹoʊ jə aʊɾ ə maɪ kæmp fəɹ biɪŋ ə spɔɪl pɹɪnsəlɪŋ wɪð tu mʌtʃ pɹaɪɾ ən nɑɾ ɪnʌf sɛns?"

"And if I don't?" Bryne asked. "If I instead throw you out of my camp for being a spoiled princeling with too much pride and not enough sense?"

ɡɔɪn fɹaʊnd. "bi kɛɹfəl, ɡɛɹɪθ. aɪv lɝn ə ɡɹeɪt dil sɪns wi læs mɛt. aɪ θɪŋk jəl faɪn ðət jəɹ sɔɹd kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɛs maɪn əz izəli əz ɪt wʌns dɪd."

Gawyn frowned. "Be careful, Gareth. I've learned a great deal since we last met. I think you'll find that your sword can no longer best mine as easily as it once did."

"aɪ hæv noʊ daʊɾ ə ðæt," bɹaɪn sɛd. "laɪt, bɔɪ! jə ɔlweɪz wɝ ə tæləntəd wʌn. bʌt jə θɪŋk ðət dʒʌs kəz jəɹ skɪld wɪð ðə sɔɹd, jəɹ wɝdz hoʊl mɔɹ weɪt? aɪ ʃəd lɪsən kəz jəl kɪl mi ɪf aɪ doʊnt? aɪ θɔɾ aɪ tɔt jə fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ðən ðæt."

"I have no doubt of that," Bryne said. "Light, boy! You always were a talented one. But you think that just because you're skilled with the sword, your words hold more weight? I should listen because you'll kill me if I don't? I thought I taught you far better than that."

bɹaɪn hæɾ eɪdʒ sɪns ɡɔɪn hæd læst sin hɪm. bʌt ðəɾ eɪdʒ dɪdn baʊ bɹaɪn daʊn - ɪt ɹɛstəd kʌmfɝɾəbli ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ə fju mɔɹ tʃɹeɪsəz ʌv waɪɾ əɾ ɪz tɛmpəlz, ə fju mɔɹ ɹɪŋkəlz ɝaʊn ði aɪz, jɛt stʃɹɔŋ ən lin ɪnʌf ə bɑɾi ðəɾ i lʊk jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ ðən i wɑz. wʌn kʊdn lʊk ət ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ən si ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ə mæn ɪn - sɝɾənli nɑt pæst - hɪz pɹaɪm.

Bryne had aged since Gawyn had last seen him. But that age didn't bow Bryne down - it rested comfortably on his shoulders. A few more traces of white at his temples, a few more wrinkles around the eyes, yet strong and lean enough of body that he looked years younger than he was. One couldn't look at Gareth Bryne and see anything other than a man in - certainly not past - his prime.

ɡɔɪn lɑkt aɪz wɪð ðə dʒɛnɝəl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ði æŋɡɝ fɹəm bɔɪlɪŋ aʊt. bɹaɪn hɛld ɪz ɡeɪz, kɑm. sɑləd. əz ə dʒɛnɝəl ʃəd bi. əz ɡɔɪn ʃəd bi.

Gawyn locked eyes with the general, trying to keep the anger from boiling out. Bryne held his gaze, calm. Solid. As a general should be. As Gawyn should be.

ɡɔɪn lʊkt əweɪ, sʌɾənli filɪŋ əʃeɪmd ə hɪmsɛlf. "laɪt," hi wɪspɝd, ɹilisɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə hɪz hɛd. hi sʌɾənli fɛl vɛɹi, vɛɹi taɪɝd. "aɪm sɑɹi, ɡɛɹɪθ. jəɹ ɹaɪt. aɪv bɪn ə ful."

Gawyn looked away, suddenly feeling ashamed of himself. "Light," he whispered, releasing his sword and raising a hand to his head. He suddenly felt very, very tired. "I'm sorry, Gareth. You're right. I've been a fool."

bɹaɪn ɡɹʌntɪd. "ɡʊd tə hɪɹ jə seɪ ðæt. aɪ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wʌndɝ wʌt hæd hæpən tə ju."

Bryne grunted. "Good to hear you say that. I was beginning to wonder what had happened to you."

ɡɔɪn saɪd, waɪpɪŋ ɪz bɹaʊ, wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ kul tə dʒɹɪŋk. hɪz æŋɡɝ mɛltəɾ əweɪ, ən i fɛlt ɪɡzɔstəd. "ɪɾ əz bɪn ə dɪfəkəl jɪɹ," hi sɛd, "æn aɪ ɹoʊd maɪsɛlf tu hɑɹd ɡɛɾɪŋ hɪɹ. aɪm ət ði ɛdʒ ə maɪ maɪnd."

Gawyn sighed, wiping his brow, wishing for something cool to drink. His anger melted away, and he felt exhausted. "It has been a difficult year," he said, "and I rode myself too hard getting here. I'm at the edge of my mind."

"ju ɑɹən ði oʊnli wʌn, læd," bɹaɪn sɛd. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən wɔk tə ə smɔl sɝvɪŋ teɪbəl, pɔɹɾ ə kʌp ə sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ɡɔɪn. ɪt wɑz oʊnli wɔɹm ti, bʌt ɡɔɪn tʊk ɪt θæŋkfəli ən sɪpt.

"You aren't the only one, lad," Bryne said. He took a deep breath and walked to a small serving table, poured a cup of something for Gawyn. It was only warm tea, but Gawyn took it thankfully and sipped.

"ðiz ɑɹ taɪmz tə tɛs mɛn," bɹaɪn sɛd, pɔɹɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ə kʌp. hi tʊk ə sɪp ən ɡɹɪməst.

"These are times to test men," Bryne said, pouring himself a cup. He took a sip and grimaced.

"wʌt?" ɡɔɪn æskt, ɡlænsɪŋ daʊn əɾ ɪz kʌp.

"What?" Gawyn asked, glancing down at his cup.

"ɪts nʌθɪŋ. aɪ dɪspaɪz ðɪs stʌf."

"It's nothing. I despise this stuff."

"ðɛn waɪ dʒɹɪŋk ɪt?" ɡɔɪn æskt.

"Then why drink it?" Gawyn asked.

"ɪts səpoʊz tə ɪmpɹuv maɪ hɛlθ," bɹaɪn ɡɹʌmbəld. bɪfɔɹ ɡɔɪn kəɾ æsk fɝðɝ, ðə lɑɹdʒ dʒɛnɝəl kəntɪnjud, "soʊ ɑɹ jə gɑnə meɪk mi θɹoʊ jə ɪn ðə stɑks bɪfɔɹ jəl tɛl mi waɪ jə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə faɪt jəɹ weɪ ɪndə maɪ kəmæn poʊst?"

"It's supposed to improve my health," Bryne grumbled. Before Gawyn could ask further, the large general continued, "So are you going to make me throw you in the stocks before you'll tell me why you decided to fight your way into my command post?"

ɡɔɪn stɛp fɔɹwɝd. "ɡɛɹɪθ. ɪts ɛɡwin. ðeɪv hɝ."

Gawyn stepped forward. "Gareth. It's Egwene. They have her."

"ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

"The White Tower Aes Sedai?"

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd ɝdʒənli.

Gawyn nodded urgently.

"aɪ noʊ." bɹaɪn tʊk ənʌðɝ dʒɹɪŋk, ðən ɡɹɪməst əɡɛn.

"I know." Bryne took another drink, then grimaced again.

"wi hæv tə ɡoʊ fəɹ hɝ!" ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪ keɪm tə æsk jə fəɹ hɛlp. aɪ ɪntɛn tə maʊn ə ɹɛskju."

"We have to go for her!" Gawyn said. "I came to ask you for help. I intend to mount a rescue."

bɹaɪn snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli. "ə ɹɛskju? ən haʊ dʒju ɪntɛn tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə waɪt taʊɝ? ivən ði il kʊdn bɹeɪk ɪndə ðət sɪɾi."

Bryne snorted softly. "A rescue? And how do you intend to get into the White Tower? Even the Aiel couldn't break into that city."

"ðeɪ dɪdnt wɑn tə," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt nid tə teɪk ðə sɪɾi, aɪ dʒʌs nid tə snik ə smɔl fɔɹs ɪn, ðən ɡɛt wʌn pɝsən aʊt. ɛvɹi ɹɑk əz ɪts kɹæks. əl faɪn ə weɪ."

"They didn't want to," Gawyn said. "But I don't need to take the city, I just need to sneak a small force in, then get one person out. Every rock has its cracks. I'll find a way."

bɹaɪn sɛɾ ɪz kʌp əsaɪd. hi lʊkt ət ɡɔɪn, fɝm, wɛðɝd feɪs ən aɪkɑn ə noʊbɪləɾi. "bʌt tɛl mi ðɪs, læd. haʊ ɑɹ jə gɑnə ɡɛɾ əɹ tə kʌm aʊt wɪð ju?"

Bryne set his cup aside. He looked at Gawyn, firm, weathered face an icon of nobility. "But tell me this, lad. How are you going to get her to come out with you?"

ɡɔɪn stɑɹɾəd. "waɪ, ʃɪl bi hæpi tə kʌm. waɪ wʊdnt ʃi?"

Gawyn started. "Why, she'll be happy to come. Why wouldn't she?"

"bɪkɔz ʃiz fɔɹbɪɾən əs tə ɹɛskju hɝ," bɹaɪn sɛd, klæspɪŋ ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk əɡɛn.

"Because she's forbidden us to rescue her," Bryne said, clasping his hands behind his back again.

"ɔɹ soʊ aɪv bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡæðɝ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tɛl mi lɪɾəl. wʌn wəd θɪŋk ðeɪd bi mɔɹ tʃɹʌstɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə mæn ðeɪ dɪpɛn ɑn tə ɹʌn ðɪs sidʒ ə ðɛɹz. ɛniweɪ, ði æmɪɝlɪn kən kəmjunəkeɪt wɪð əm sʌmhaʊ, ən ʃiz ɪnstʃɹʌktəɾ əm tə liv əɹ bi."

"Or so I've been able to gather. The Aes Sedai tell me little. One would think they'd be more trusting toward a man they depend on to run this siege of theirs. Anyway, the Amyrlin can communicate with them somehow, and she's instructed them to leave her be."

wʌt? ðət wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs! ɑbviəsli, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn kæmp wɝ fʌdʒɪŋ ðə fæks. "bɹaɪn, ʃiz ɪmpɹɪzənd! ði ɛɛs sədaɪ aɪ hɝd tɔkɪŋ sɛd ðət ʃiz biɪŋ biɾən deɪli. ðəl ɛksəkjut hɝ!"

What? That was ridiculous! Obviously, the Aes Sedai in camp were fudging the facts. "Bryne, she's imprisoned! The Aes Sedai I heard talking said that she's being beaten daily. They'll execute her!"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ʃiz bɪn wɪð əm fəɹ wiks naʊ ən ðeɪ hævən kɪld əɹ jɛt."

"I don't know," Bryne said. "She's been with them for weeks now and they haven't killed her yet."

"ðeɪl kɪl hɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛɾ ɝdʒənli. "ju noʊ ðeɪ wɪl. pɝhæps jə pɝeɪɾ ə fɔlən ɛnəmi bɪfɔɹ jəɹ soʊlʒɝz fəɹ ə taɪm, bʌɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli juv tə maʊn ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ə paɪk tə lɛɾ əm noʊ hiz dɛɾ ən ɡɔn. jə noʊ aɪm ɹaɪt."
