"They'll kill her," Gawyn said urgently. "You know they will. Perhaps you parade a fallen enemy before your soldiers for a time, but eventually you have to mount his head on a pike to let them know he's dead and gone. You know I'm right."

bɹaɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾəd hɪm, ðən nɑɾəd. "pɝhæps aɪ du. bʌt ðɛɹz stɪl nʌθɪŋ aɪ kən du. aɪm baʊn baɪ oʊðz, ɡɔɪn. aɪ kæn də ɛniθɪŋ ənlɛs ðət ɡɝl ɪnstʃɹʌks mi tə."

Bryne regarded him, then nodded. "Perhaps I do. But there's still nothing I can do. I'm bound by oaths, Gawyn. I can't do anything unless that girl instructs me to."

"jud lɛɾ əɹ daɪ?"

"You'd let her die?"

"ɪf ðæts wʌɾ ɪt teɪks tə kip maɪ oʊθ, ðən jɛs."

"If that's what it takes to keep my oath, then yes."

ɪf bɹaɪn wɑz baʊn baɪ oʊθ . . . wɛl, hid sunɝ hɪɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tɛl ə laɪ ðən si ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn bɹeɪk ɪz wɝd. bʌɾ ɛɡwin! ðəɹ hæd tə bi sʌmθɪŋ i kəd du!

If Bryne was bound by oath . . . well, he'd sooner hear an Aes Sedai tell a lie than see Gareth Bryne break his word. But Egwene! There had to be something he could do!

"aɪl tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛt jə ən ɑɾiəns wɪð səm ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ aɪ sɝv," bɹaɪn sɛd. "pɝhæps ðeɪ kən də sʌmθɪŋ. ɪf jə pɝsweɪɾ əm ðəɾ ə ɹɛskju ɪz niɾəd, ən ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn wəd wɑn ɪt, ðən wɪl si."

"I'll try to get you an audience with some of the Aes Sedai I serve," Bryne said. "Perhaps they can do something. If you persuade them that a rescue is needed, and that the Amyrlin would want it, then we'll see."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd. ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ət list. "θæŋk ju."

Gawyn nodded. It was something at least. "Thank you."

bɹaɪn weɪvd ɪndɪfɹənli. "ðoʊ aɪ ʃəd si jə ɪn ðə stɑks. fəɹ wundɪŋ θɹi ʌv maɪ mɛn, ɪf nʌθɪŋ ɛls."

Bryne waved indifferently. "Though I should see you in the stocks. For wounding three of my men, if nothing else."

"hæv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hil ðɛm," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "fɹʌm wʌɾ aɪv hɝd, juv noʊ læk ə sɪstɝz tə bʊli ju."

"Have an Aes Sedai Heal them," Gawyn said. "From what I've heard, you've no lack of sisters to bully you."

"bɑ," bɹaɪn sɛd. "aɪ kən ɹɛɹli ɡɛɾ əm tə hil ɛniwʌn ənlɛs ðə soʊlʒɝz laɪf ɪz θɹɛɾənd. aɪ hæɾ ə mæn teɪk ə bæd spɪl waɪl ɹaɪɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ deɪ, ən aɪ wɑz toʊl ðət hilɪŋ wəɾ oʊnli titʃ ɪm tə bi ɹɛkləs. 'peɪn ɪz ɪts oʊn lɛsən,' ðə blæstəd wʊmən sɛd. 'pɝhæps nɛks taɪm i woʊn si fɪt tə meɪk spɔɹt fəɹ ɪz fɹɛnz waɪl ɹaɪɾɪŋ.' "

"Bah," Bryne said. "I can rarely get them to Heal anyone unless the soldier's life is threatened. I had a man take a bad spill while riding the other day, and I was told that Healing would only teach him to be reckless. 'Pain is its own lesson,' the blasted woman said. 'Perhaps next time he won't see fit to make sport for his friends while riding.' "

ɡɔɪn ɡɹɪməst. "bʌt ʃʊɹli ðəl meɪk ən ɪksɛpʃən fəɹ ðoʊz mɛn. æftɝ ɔl, ən ɛnəmi dɪd də ðə wundɪŋ."

Gawyn grimaced. "But surely they'll make an exception for those men. After all, an enemy did do the wounding."

"wil si," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ðə sɪstɝz ɹɛɹli vɪzət ðə soʊlʒɝz. ðeɪv ðɛɹ oʊn bɪznəs tə bi əbaʊt."

"We'll see," Bryne said. "The sisters rarely visit the soldiers. They've their own business to be about."

"ðɛɹz wʌn ɪn ði aʊɾɝ kæmp naʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛɾ æbsənli, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

"There's one in the outer camp now," Gawyn said absently, glancing over his shoulder.

"jʌŋɡɝ ɡɝl? dɑɹk hɛɹ, wɪθaʊt ði eɪdʒləs feɪs?"

"Younger girl? Dark hair, without the ageless face?"

"noʊ, ðɪs wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ kəd tɛl kəz ə ðə feɪs. ʃi wɑz kaɪndə plʌmp, wɪð laɪɾɝ hɛɹ."

"No, this was an Aes Sedai. I could tell because of the face. She was kind of plump, with lighter hair."

"pɹɑbli dʒʌst skaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ wɔɹɾɝz," bɹaɪn sɛd, saɪɪŋ. "ðeɪ də ðæt."

"Probably just scouting for Warders," Bryne said, sighing. "They do that."

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk soʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ʃi wɑz haɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə wɑʃwɪmən." əz i θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, hi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi kəd vɛɹi wɛl bi ə spaɪ fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ lɔɪəlɪsts.

"I don't think so," Gawyn said, glancing over his shoulder. "She was hiding among the washwomen." As he thought about it, he realized that she could very well be a spy for the White Tower loyalists.

bɹaɪnz fɹaʊn dipənd. pɝhæps i hæd ðə seɪm θɔts. "ʃoʊ mi," hi sɛd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə tɛn flæps. hi θɹu ðɛm əsaɪd, wɔkɪŋ bæk aʊɾ ɪndə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt, ɡɔɪn fɑloʊɪŋ.

Bryne's frown deepened. Perhaps he had the same thoughts. "Show me," he said, striding toward the tent flaps. He threw them aside, walking back out into the morning light, Gawyn following.

"ju nɛvɝ dɪɾ ɪkspleɪn wʌt jə ɑɹ duɪŋ hɪɹ, ɡɔɪn," bɹaɪn sɛɾ əz ðeɪ wɔk θɹu ði ɔɹɾɝli kæmp, soʊlʒɝz səluɾɪŋ ðɛɹ dʒɛnɝəl əz i pæst.

"You never did explain what you are doing here, Gawyn," Bryne said as they walked through the orderly camp, soldiers saluting their general as he passed.

"aɪ toʊl ju," ɡɔɪn sɛd, hæn ɹɛstɪŋ kʌmfɝɾəbli ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sɔɹd. "aɪ æm gɑnə faɪn ə weɪ tə ɡɛɾ ɛɡwin aʊɾ ə ðət dɛθ tʃɹæp."

"I told you," Gawyn said, hand resting comfortably on the pommel of his sword. "I am going to find a way to get Egwene out of that death trap."

"aɪ dɪdn min wʌt jəɹ duɪŋ ɪn maɪ kæmp. aɪ mɛnt waɪ jə wɝ ɪn ði ɛɹiə ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs.

"I didn't mean what you're doing in my camp. I meant why you were in the area in the first place.

waɪ ɑɹən jə bæk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, hɛlpɪŋ jəɹ sɪstɝ?"

Why aren't you back in Caemlyn, helping your sister?"

"ju hæv nuz ʌv ɪleɪn," ɡɔɪn sɛd, stɑpɪŋ. laɪt! hi ʃʊɾə æskt ɝliɝ. hi ɹɪli wɑz taɪɝd. "aɪ hɝd ðət ʃi wɑz ɪn jəɹ kæmp ɝliɝ. ʃiz ɡɔn bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn? ɪz ʃi seɪf?"

"You have news of Elayne," Gawyn said, stopping. Light! He should have asked earlier. He really was tired. "I heard that she was in your camp earlier. She's gone back to Caemlyn? Is she safe?"

"ʃi hæzən bɪn wɪð əs fəɹ ə lɔŋ waɪl," bɹaɪn sɛd. "bʌt ʃi simz tə bi duɪŋ wɛl." hi stɑpt, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ɡɔɪn. "ju min jə doʊnt noʊ?"

"She hasn't been with us for a long while," Bryne said. "But she seems to be doing well." He stopped, glancing at Gawyn. "You mean you don't know?"

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"wɛl, ɹumɝz ɑɹ ʌnɹɪlaɪəbəl," bɹaɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ hæv kənfɝmd mɛni ʌv əm wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu hæv bɪn tʃɹævlɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn tə lɪsən fəɹ nuz. jəɹ sɪstɝ hoʊlz ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. ɪt simz ðət ʃiz əndʌn mʌtʃ ə ðə mɛs jəɹ mʌðɝ lɛft fəɹ hɝ."

"Well, rumors are unreliable," Bryne said. "But I have confirmed many of them with the Aes Sedai, who have been Traveling to Caemlyn to listen for news. Your sister holds the Lion Throne. It seems that she's undone much of the mess your mother left for her."

ɡɔɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. θæŋk ðə laɪt, hi θɔt, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz. ɪleɪn lɪvd. ɪleɪn hɛl ðə θɹoʊn. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz, ən ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ simd ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ bɹaɪt. hi kəntɪnjud wɔkɪŋ, bɹaɪn fɔlɪŋ ɪndə stɛp bɪsaɪd hɪm.

Gawyn took a deep breath. Thank the Light, he thought, closing his eyes. Elayne lived. Elayne held the throne. He opened his eyes, and the overcast sky seemed a little more bright. He continued walking, Bryne falling into step beside him.

"ju ɹɪli dɪdnt noʊ," bɹaɪn sɛd. "wɛɹ əv jə bɪn, læd? jəɹ ðə fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd naʊ, əɹ jəl bi wʌns jə ɹɪtɝn tə keɪɛmlɪn! jəɹ pleɪs ɪz ət jəɹ sɪstɝz saɪd."

"You really didn't know," Bryne said. "Where have you been, lad? You're the First Prince of the Sword now, or you will be once you return to Caemlyn! Your place is at your sister's side."

"ɛɡwin fɝst."

"Egwene first."

"ju meɪɾ ən oʊθ," bɹaɪn sɛd stɝnli. "bɪfɔɹ mi. hæv jə fɝɡɑɾən?"

"You made an oath," Bryne said sternly. "Before me. Have you forgotten?"

"noʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪf ɪleɪn əz ðə θɹoʊn, ðən ʃiz seɪf fəɹ naʊ. əl ɡɛɾ ɛɡwin ən toʊ hɝ bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn wɛɹ aɪ kən kip ən aɪ ɑn hɝ. wɛɹ aɪ kən kip ən aɪ ɑn boʊθ ə ðɛm."

"No," Gawyn said. "But if Elayne has the throne, then she's safe for now. I'll get Egwene and tow her back to Caemlyn where I can keep an eye on her. Where I can keep an eye on both of them."

bɹaɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪd laɪk tə wɑtʃ jə tʃɹaɪɪŋ ðət fɝs pɑɹt," hi noʊɾəd. "bʌt ɹəɡɑɹdləs, waɪ wɝn jə ðəɹ wən ɪleɪn wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk ðə θɹoʊn? wʌɾ əv jə bɪn duɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ðæt?"

Bryne snorted. "I think I'd like to watch you trying that first part," he noted. "But regardless, why weren't you there when Elayne was trying to take the throne? What have you been doing that is more important than that?"

"aɪ . . . ɡɹu ɛntæŋɡəld," ɡɔɪn sɛd, aɪz fɔɹwɝd.

"I . . . grew entangled," Gawyn said, eyes forward.

"ɛntæŋɡəld?" bɹaɪn æskt. "ju wɝ ət ðə waɪt taʊɝ wən ɔl ə ðɪs - " hi kʌɾ ɔf, fɔlɪŋ saɪlənt. ðə tu wɔk saɪd baɪ saɪd fəɹ ə moʊmənt.

"Entangled?" Bryne asked. "You were at the White Tower when all of this - " He cut off, falling silent. The two walked side by side for a moment.

"wɛɹ dɪd jə hɪɹ sɪstɝz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛɡwinz kæptʃɝ?" bɹaɪn æskt. "haʊ wəd jə noʊ ʃiz biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt?"

"Where did you hear sisters talking about Egwene's capture?" Bryne asked. "How would you know she's being punished?"

ɡɔɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Gawyn said nothing.

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!" bɹaɪn ɪkskleɪmd. ðə dʒɛnɝəl ɹɛɹli kɝst. "aɪ nu ðət ðə pɝsən liɾɪŋ ðoʊz ɹeɪdz əɡɛns mi wɑz tu wɛl ɪnfɔɹmd. ən hɪɹ aɪ wɑz, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə lik əmʌŋ maɪ ɔfəsɝz!"

"Blood and bloody ashes!" Bryne exclaimed. The general rarely cursed. "I knew that the person leading those raids against me was too well informed. And here I was, looking for a leak among my officers!"

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ naʊ."

"It doesn't matter now."

"aɪl dʒʌdʒ ðæt," bɹaɪn sɛd. "juv bɪn kɪlɪŋ maɪ mɛn. liɾɪŋ ɹeɪdz əɡɛns mi!"

"I'll judge that," Bryne said. "You've been killing my men. Leading raids against me!"

"liɾɪŋ ɹeɪdz əɡɛns ðə ɹɛbəlz," ɡɔɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ hɑɹɾ aɪz ɑn bɹaɪn. "ju meɪ bleɪm mi fəɹ bʊliɪŋ maɪ weɪ ɪndə jəɹ kæmp, bʌt dʒju ɑnəsli ɪkspɛk mi tə fil ɡɪlti fəɹ hɛlpɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ əɡɛns ðə fɔɹs bɪsidʒɪŋ ɪt?"

"Leading raids against the rebels," Gawyn said, turning hard eyes on Bryne. "You may blame me for bullying my way into your camp, but do you honestly expect me to feel guilty for helping the White Tower against the force besieging it?"

bɹaɪn fɛl saɪlənt. ðən i nɑɾəd kɝtli. "vɛɹi wɛl. bʌt ðət meɪks jə ən ɛnəmi kəmændɝ."

Bryne fell silent. Then he nodded curtly. "Very well. But that makes you an enemy commander."

"noʊ lɔŋɡɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪv lɛf ðət kəmænd."

"No longer," Gawyn said. "I've left that command."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"aɪ hɛlp ðɛm," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ du. nʌθɪŋ aɪ si hɪɹ wɪl ɹɪtɝn tə jəɹ ɛnəmiz, bɹaɪn. aɪ swɛɹ ɪɾ ɑn ðə laɪt."

"I helped them," Gawyn said. "I no longer do. Nothing I see here will return to your enemies, Bryne. I swear it on the Light."

bɹaɪn dɪdn ɹɪspɑn ɪmiɾiətli. ðeɪ pæs tɛns, laɪkli fəɹ ðə haɪ ɔfəsɝz, əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə pælɪsɑd wɔl. "vɛɹi wɛl," bɹaɪn sɛd. "aɪ kən tʃɹʌs jə hævən tʃeɪnʒd ɪnʌf tə bɹeɪk jəɹ wɝd."

Bryne didn't respond immediately. They passed tents, likely for the high officers, approaching the palisade wall. "Very well," Bryne said. "I can trust you haven't changed enough to break your word."

"aɪ wʊdn tɝn əɡɛns ðəɾ oʊθ," ɡɔɪn sɛd hɑɹʃli. "haʊ kəd jə θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪ wʊd?"

"I wouldn't turn against that oath," Gawyn said harshly. "How could you think that I would?"

"aɪv hæɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð ʌnɪkspɛktɪd ɹɛnʌnsieɪʃənz ʌv oʊðz leɪtli," bɹaɪn sɛd. "aɪ sɛɾ aɪ bɪliv ju, læd. ən aɪ du. bʌt jə stɪl hævən ɪkspleɪnd waɪ jə dɪdn ɹɪtɝn tə keɪɛmlɪn."

"I've had experience with unexpected renunciations of oaths lately," Bryne said. "I said I believe you, lad. And I do. But you still haven't explained why you didn't return to Caemlyn."

"ɛɡwin wɑz wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "æz fɑɹ əz aɪ nu, ɪleɪn wɑz əz wɛl. ðɪs simd ə ɡʊd pleɪs tə bi, ɔlðoʊ aɪ wɑzn sɝɾən aɪ laɪkt ɪleɪɾəz əθɔɹəɾi."

"Egwene was with the Aes Sedai," Gawyn said. "As far as I knew, Elayne was as well. This seemed a good place to be, although I wasn't certain I liked Elaida's authority."

"ænd wʌɾ ɪz ɛɡwin tə ju?" bɹaɪn æsk sɔfli.

"And what is Egwene to you?" Bryne asked softly.

ɡɔɪn mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ," hi ədmɪɾəd. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ dɪd."

Gawyn met his eyes. "I don't know," he admitted. "I wish I did."

stʃɹeɪnʒli, bɹaɪn tʃʌkəld. "aɪ si. ən aɪ ʌndɝstænd. kʌm, lɛts faɪn ðɪs ɛɛs sədaɪ jə θɪŋk jə sɔ."

Strangely, Bryne chuckled. "I see. And I understand. Come, let's find this Aes Sedai you think you saw."

"aɪ dɪd si hɝ, ɡɛɹɪθ," ɡɔɪn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə ɡɑɹdz əz ðeɪ pæst aʊt ðə ɡeɪts. ðə mɛn səluɾəd bɹaɪn, bʌt wɑtʃt ɡɔɪn əz ðeɪ wəɾ ə blækləns. əz wɛl ðeɪ ʃʊd.

"I did see her, Gareth," Gawyn said, nodding to the guards as they passed out the gates. The men saluted Bryne, but watched Gawyn as they would a blacklance. As well they should.

"wi ʃæl si wʌt wi faɪnd," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ɹəɡɑɹdləs, wʌns aɪ ɡɛt jə ə miɾɪŋ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ liɾɝz, aɪ wɑn jəɹ wɝd ðət jəl ɡoʊ bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn. liv ɛɡwin tə ʌs. jə nid tə hɛlp ɪleɪn. ɪts jəɹ pleɪs tə bi ɪn ændɝ."

"We shall see what we find," Bryne said. "Regardless, once I get you a meeting with the Aes Sedai leaders, I want your word that you'll go back to Caemlyn. Leave Egwene to us. You need to help Elayne. It's your place to be in Andor."

"aɪ kəd seɪ ðə seɪm ə ju." ɡɔɪn sɝveɪd ðə timɪŋ fɑloʊɝz' kæmp. wɛɹ hæd ðə wʊmən bɪn?

"I could say the same of you." Gawyn surveyed the teeming followers' camp. Where had the woman been?

"ju kʊd," bɹaɪn sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ. "bʌɾ ɪt wʊdn bi tʃɹu. jəɹ mʌðɝ sɔ tə ðæt."

"You could," Bryne said gruffly. "But it wouldn't be true. Your mother saw to that."

ɡɔɪn ɡlænst ət hɪm.

Gawyn glanced at him.

"ʃi pʊt mi aʊt tə pæstʃɝ, ɡɔɪn. bænɪʃt mi ən θɹɛɾənd mi wɪð dɛθ."

"She put me out to pasture, Gawyn. Banished me and threatened me with death."

"ɪmpɑsəbəl!"

"Impossible!"

bɹaɪn lʊkt ɡɹɪm. "aɪ fɛl ðə seɪm weɪ. bʌɾ ɪts tʃɹu nʌnðəlɛs. ðə θɪŋz ʃi sɛd . . . ðeɪ stʌŋ, ɡɔɪn. ðət ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪndid."

Bryne looked grim. "I felt the same way. But it is true nonetheless. The things she said . . . they stung, Gawyn. That they did indeed."

ðət wɑz ɔl bɹaɪn sɛd, bʌt fɹəm hɪm, ɪt spoʊk vɑljumz. ɡɔɪn hæd nɛvɝ hɝd ðə mæn ɔfɝ ə wɝɾ ə dɪskəntɛn əbaʊɾ ɪz steɪʃən əɹ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz. hi hæd bɪn lɔɪəl tə mɔɹɡeɪs - lɔɪəl wɪð ðə kaɪndə stɛdfæsnəs ə ɹulɝ kəɾ oʊnli hoʊp fɔɹ. ɡɔɪn hæd nɛvɝ noʊn ə mæn mɔɹ ʃʊɹ, əɹ ə mæn lɛs laɪkli tə kəmpleɪn.

That was all Bryne said, but from him, it spoke volumes. Gawyn had never heard the man offer a word of discontent about his station or his orders. He had been loyal to Morgase - loyal with the kind of steadfastness a ruler could only hope for. Gawyn had never known a man more sure, or a man less likely to complain.

"ɪt mʌst əv bɪn pɑɹɾ ə səm skim," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ju noʊ mʌðɝ. ɪf ʃi hɝt ju, ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹizən."

"It must have been part of some scheme," Gawyn said. "You know Mother. If she hurt you, there was a reason."

bɹaɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ ɹizən ʌðɝ ðən fulɪʃ lʌv fəɹ ðət fɑp ɡeɪbɹəl. ʃi nɪɹli lɛɾ əɹ klaʊɾəd hɛd ɹuən ændɝ."

Bryne shook his head. "No reason other than foolish love for that fop Gaebril. She nearly let her clouded head ruin Andor."

"ʃid nɛvɝ!" ɡɔɪn snæpt. "ɡɛɹɪθ, jə ʌv ɔl pipəl ʃəd noʊ ðæt!"

"She'd never!" Gawyn snapped. "Gareth, you of all people should know that!"

"aɪ ʃʊd," bɹaɪn sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs. "æn aɪ wɪʃ aɪ dɪd."

"I should," Bryne said, lowering his voice. "And I wish I did."

"ʃi hæɾ ənʌðɝ moʊɾɪv," ɡɔɪn sɛd stʌbɝnli. hi fɛl ðə hiɾ ʌv æŋɡɝ ɹaɪz wɪðɪn ɪm əɡɛn.

"She had another motive," Gawyn said stubbornly. He felt the heat of anger rise within him again.

ɝaʊn ðɛm, pɛdlɝz ɡlænst ət ðə tu, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ðeɪ pɹɑbli nu nɑt tə əpɹoʊtʃ bɹaɪn. "bʌt naʊ wɪl nɛvɝ noʊ ɪt. nɑt naʊ ðət ʃiz dɛd. kɝs ælθɹ! ðə deɪ kæn kʌm sun ɪnʌf wən aɪ kən ɹʌn ɪm θɹu."

Around them, peddlers glanced at the two, but said nothing. They probably knew not to approach Bryne. "But now we'll never know it. Not now that she's dead. Curse al'Thor! The day can't come soon enough when I can run him through."

bɹaɪn lʊkt ət ɡɔɪn ʃɑɹpli. "ælθɹ seɪvd ændɝ, sʌn. əɹ əz nɪɹ tə ɪɾ əz ə mæn kʊd."

Bryne looked at Gawyn sharply. "Al'Thor saved Andor, son. Or as near to it as a man could."

"haʊ kəd jə seɪ ðæt?" ɡɔɪn sɛd. "haʊ kəd jə spik wɛl ə ðət mɑnstɝ? hi kɪl maɪ mʌðɝ!"

"How could you say that?" Gawyn said. "How could you speak well of that monster? He killed my mother!"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf aɪ bɪliv ðoʊz ɹumɝz əɹ nɑt," bɹaɪn sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "bʌɾ ɪf aɪ du, læd, ðən pɝhæps i dɪɾ ændɝ ə feɪvɝ. jə doʊnt noʊ haʊ bæɾ ɪt ɡɑt, ðəɹ ət ði ɛnd."

"I don't know if I believe those rumors or not," Bryne said, rubbing his chin. "But if I do, lad, then perhaps he did Andor a favor. You don't know how bad it got, there at the end."

"aɪ kæn bɪliv aɪm hɪɹɪŋ ðɪs," ɡɔɪn sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz hæn tə hɪz sɔɹd. "aɪ woʊn hɪɹ əɹ neɪm sɔɪld laɪk ðæt, bɹaɪn. aɪ min ɪt."

"I can't believe I'm hearing this," Gawyn said, lowering his hand to his sword. "I won't hear her name soiled like that, Bryne. I mean it."

bɹaɪn lʊkt ɪm dɝɛkli ɪn ði aɪz. hɪz ɡeɪz wɑz soʊ sɑləd. laɪk aɪz kɑɹvd ʌv ɡɹænət. "aɪl ɔlweɪz spik tʃɹuθ, ɡɔɪn. noʊ mæɾɝ u tʃælənʒɪz mi ɑn ɪt. ɪts hɑɹd tə hɪɹ? wɛl, ɪt wɑz hɑɹɾɝ tə lɪv. noʊ ɡʊd kʌmz ə spɹɛɾɪŋ kəmpleɪns. bʌɾ əɹ sʌn nidz tə noʊ. ɪn ði ɛnd, ɡɔɪn, jəɹ mʌðɝ tɝn əɡɛnst ændɝ baɪ ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ɡeɪbɹəl. ʃi niɾəd tə bi ɹimuvd. ɪf ælθɹ dɪd ðət fəɹ ʌs, ðən wɪv nid tə θæŋk hɪm."

Bryne looked him directly in the eyes. His gaze was so solid. Like eyes carved of granite. "I'll always speak truth, Gawyn. No matter who challenges me on it. It's hard to hear? Well, it was harder to live. No good comes of spreading complaints. But her son needs to know. In the end, Gawyn, your mother turned against Andor by embracing Gaebril. She needed to be removed. If al'Thor did that for us, then we have need to thank him."

ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ɹeɪdʒ ən ʃɑk faɪɾɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðɪs wɑz ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn?

Gawyn shook his head, rage and shock fighting one another. This was Gareth Bryne?

"ðiz ɑɹən ðə wɝdz ʌv ə spɝn lʌvɝ," bɹaɪn sɛd, feɪs sɛt, əz ɪf ʃʌvɪŋ əsaɪɾ ɪmoʊʃənz.

"These aren't the words of a spurned lover," Bryne said, face set, as if shoving aside emotions.

hi spoʊk sɔfli əz i ən ɡɔɪn wɔkt, kæmp fɑloʊɝz ɡɪvɪŋ əm ə waɪd bɝθ. "aɪ kən æksɛp ðəɾ ə wʊmən kəd luz əfɛkʃən fəɹ ə mæn ən bɪstoʊ ɪɾ ɑn ənʌðɝ. jɛs, mɔɹɡeɪs ðə wʊmən aɪ kən fɝɡɪv. bʌt mɔɹɡeɪs ðə kwin? ʃi ɡeɪv ðə kɪŋdəm tə ðət sneɪk. ʃi sɛn əɹ ælaɪz tə bi biɾən ən ɪmpɹɪzənd. ʃi wɑzn ɹaɪɾ ɪn əɹ maɪnd. səmtaɪmz, wən ə soʊlʒɝz ɑɹm fɛstɝz, ɪt nidz tə bi kʌt fɹi tə seɪv ðə mænz laɪf. aɪm plizd əɾ ɪleɪnz səksɛs, ən ɪts ə waʊn tə spik ðiz wɝdz. bʌt juv tə bɛɹi ðət heɪtʃɹəɾ ʌv ælθɹ. hi wɑzn ðə pɹɑbləm. jəɹ mʌðɝ wɑz."

He spoke softly as he and Gawyn walked, camp followers giving them a wide berth. "I can accept that a woman could lose affection for a man and bestow it on another. Yes, Morgase the woman I can forgive. But Morgase the Queen? She gave the kingdom to that snake. She sent her allies to be beaten and imprisoned. She wasn't right in her mind. Sometimes, when a soldier's arm festers, it needs to be cut free to save the man's life. I'm pleased at Elayne's success, and it is a wound to speak these words. But you have to bury that hatred of al'Thor. He wasn't the problem. Your mother was."

ɡɔɪn kɛpt ɪz tiθ klɛntʃt. nɛvɝ, hi θɔt. əl nɛvɝ fɝɡɪv ælθɹ. nɑt fəɹ ðɪs.

Gawyn kept his teeth clenched. Never, he thought. I will never forgive al'Thor. Not for this.

"aɪ kən si ði ɪntɛn bɪhaɪn ðət lʊk," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ɔl ðə mɔɹ ɹizən tə ɡɛt jə bæk tə ændɝ.

"I can see the intent behind that look," Bryne said. "All the more reason to get you back to Andor.

jəl si. ɪf jə doʊn tʃɹʌs mi, æsk jəɹ sɪstɝ. si wʌt ʃi sɛz ʌv ɪt."

You'll see. If you don't trust me, ask your sister. See what she says of it."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd ʃɑɹpli. ɪnʌf ə ðæt. əhɛd, hi noʊɾəd ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hid sin ðə wʊmən.

Gawyn nodded sharply. Enough of that. Ahead, he noted the place where he'd seen the woman.

hi ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə dɪstən laɪnz ʌv wɑʃwɪmən, ðən tɝn ən stʃɹoʊd təwɔɹd ðɛm, ɛdʒɪŋ bɪtwin tu mɝtʃəns wɪð pʌnʒənt pɛnz fʊl ə tʃɪkənz, sɛlɪŋ ɛɡz. "ðɪs weɪ," hi sɛd, pɝhæps tu ʃɑɹpli.

He glanced toward the distant lines of washwomen, then turned and strode toward them, edging between two merchants with pungent pens full of chickens, selling eggs. "This way," he said, perhaps too sharply.

hi dɪdn lʊk tə si ɪf bɹaɪn fɑloʊd. sun ðə dʒɛnɝəl kɑɾ ʌp tə hɪm, lʊkɪŋ dɪsplizd, bʌɾ i kɛpt ɪz pis. ðeɪ wɔk daʊn ə kɹaʊɾəd, twɪstɪŋ pæθweɪ əmʌŋ pipəl ɪn bɹaʊnz ən dʌl ɡɹeɪz, ən sun ɹitʃt ðə laɪn ʌv wɪmən nilɪŋ bɪfɔɹ tu lɔŋ wʊɾən tʃɹɔfs ə sloʊli floʊɪŋ wɔɾɝ. mɛn stʊɾ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛnd, pɔɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ daʊn ðə tʃɹɔfs, ən ðə laɪn ʌv wɪmən wɑʃt kloʊðɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌdzi wʌn, ðən ɹɪnst əm ɔf ɪn ðə klinɝ tʃɹɔf. noʊ wʌndɝ ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz soʊ wɛt! ət lis hɪɹ ɪt smɛld ə sʌdz ən klɛnlinɪs.

He didn't look to see if Bryne followed. Soon the general caught up to him, looking displeased, but he kept his peace. They walked down a crowded, twisting pathway among people in browns and dull grays, and soon reached the line of women kneeling before two long wooden troughs of slowly flowing water. Men stood at the far end, pouring water down the troughs, and the line of women washed clothing in the sudsy one, then rinsed them off in the cleaner trough. No wonder the ground was so wet! At least here it smelled of suds and cleanliness.

ðə wɪmən hæd ðɛɹ slivz ɹoʊld ʌp tə ðɛɹ ʌpɝ ɑɹmz, ən moʊst ə ðɛm tʃæɾəd aɪdli əz ðeɪ wɝkt, ɹʌbɪŋ kloʊðɪŋ əɡɛns bɔɹdz ɪn ðə tʃɹɔfs. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dʒɹɛst ɪn ðoʊz seɪm bɹaʊn skɝts i hæd sin ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɡɔɪn ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hæn aɪdli ɑn ɪz pɑməl, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə wɪmən fɹəm bɪhaɪnd.

The women had their sleeves rolled up to their upper arms, and most of them chatted idly as they worked, rubbing clothing against boards in the troughs. They were all dressed in those same brown skirts he had seen on the Aes Sedai. Gawyn rested his hand idly on his pommel, inspecting the women from behind.

"wɪtʃ wʌn?" bɹaɪn æskt.

"Which one?" Bryne asked.

"dʒʌst ə moʊmənt," ɡɔɪn sɛd. ðəɹ wɝ dʌzənz ʌv wɪmən. hæɾ i ɹɪli sin wʌt hid θɔt? waɪ wəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ bi ɪn ðɪs kæmp, ʌv ɔl pleɪsəz? ʃʊɹli ɪleɪɾə wʊdn sɛn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊt tə spaɪ; ðɛɹ feɪsəz meɪɾ əm tu izi tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz.

"Just a moment," Gawyn said. There were dozens of women. Had he really seen what he'd thought? Why would an Aes Sedai be in this camp, of all places? Surely Elaida wouldn't send an Aes Sedai out to spy; their faces made them too easy to recognize.

ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ðəɾ izi tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz, waɪ kʊdn i spɑɾ əɹ naʊ?

Of course, if they were that easy to recognize, why couldn't he spot her now?

ən ðən i sɔ hɝ. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ði oʊnli wɪmən u wɑzn tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz ɝaʊn hɝ.

And then he saw her. She was one of the only women who wasn't chatting with those around her.

ʃi nɛlt wɪð əɹ hɛd baʊd, ðə jɛloʊ kɝtʃəf taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ hɛd, ʃeɪɾɪŋ əɹ feɪs, ə fju lɑks ə laɪt hɛɹ stɪkɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə klɔθ. hɝ pɑstʃɝ wɑz soʊ səbsɝviən ðəɾ i ɔlmoʊs mɪs hɝ, bʌt ðə ʃeɪp ə hɝ bɑɾi stʊɾ aʊt. ʃi wɑz plʌmp, ən ðət kɝtʃəf wɑz ði oʊnli jɛloʊ wʌn ɪn ðə laɪn.

She knelt with her head bowed, the yellow kerchief tied around her head, shading her face, a few locks of light hair sticking out from under the cloth. Her posture was so subservient that he almost missed her, but the shape of her body stood out. She was plump, and that kerchief was the only yellow one in the line.

ɡɔɪn stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə laɪn ʌv wɝkɪŋ wɪmən, sɛvɹəl ə hum stʊɾ ʌp, hænz ɑn hɪps əz ðeɪ ɪkspleɪn ɪn noʊ ənsɝɾən tɝmz ðət "soʊlʒɝz wɪð ðɛɹ bɪɡ fiɾ ən ɑkwɝɾ ɛlboʊz" ʃəd steɪ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv wɪmən ət wɝk. ɡɔɪn ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm, pɹɛsɪŋ ɑn əntɪl i stʊd bɪsaɪd ðə jɛloʊ kɝtʃəf.

Gawyn strode down the line of working women, several of whom stood up, hands on hips as they explained in no uncertain terms that "Soldiers with their big feet and awkward elbows" should stay out of the way of women at work. Gawyn ignored them, pressing on until he stood beside the yellow kerchief.

ðɪs ɪz ɪnseɪn, ɡɔɪn θɔt. ðɛɹz nɛvɝ ɪn ɔl ə hɪstɝi bɪn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu kəd fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə ədɑp ðət kaɪndə pɑstʃɝ.

This is insane, Gawyn thought. There's never in all of history been an Aes Sedai who could force herself to adopt that kind of posture.

bɹaɪn stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɡɔɪn stup daʊn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ə lʊk ət ðə wʊmənz feɪs. ʃi baʊd daʊn fɝðɝ, skɹʌbɪŋ mɔɹ fjʊɹiəsli ət ðə ʃɝɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɔf bɪfɔɹ hɝ.

Bryne stepped up beside him. Gawyn stooped down, trying to get a look at the woman's face. She bowed down further, scrubbing more furiously at the shirt in the trough before her.

"wʊmən," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "meɪ aɪ si jəɹ feɪs?"

"Woman," Gawyn said. "May I see your face?"

ʃi dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd. ɡɔɪn lʊkt ʌp ət bɹaɪn. hɛzɪɾəntli, ðə dʒɛnɝəl ɹitʃt daʊn ən pʊʃt bæk ðə plʌmp wʊmənz kɝtʃəf. ðə feɪs ʌndɝniθ wɑz dɪstɪŋkli ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪð ðəɾ ʌnmɪsteɪkəbəl eɪdʒləs kwɑləɾi. ʃi dɪdn lʊk ʌp. ʃi dʒʌs kɛpt wɝkɪŋ.

She didn't respond. Gawyn looked up at Bryne. Hesitantly, the general reached down and pushed back the plump woman's kerchief. The face underneath was distinctly Aes Sedai, with that unmistakable ageless quality. She didn't look up. She just kept working.

"aɪ sɛɾ ɪt wʊdnt wɝk," sɛɾ ə hɛfti wʊmən nɪɹbaɪ. ðə wʊmən ɹoʊz ən wɑɾəld daʊn ðə laɪn, wɛɹɪŋ ə tɛntlaɪk dʒɹɛs ʌv ɡɹin ən bɹaʊn. " 'maɪ leɪɾi,' aɪ toʊl hɝ, 'ju kən də əz jə wɪʃ, aɪ eɪnt wʌn tə ɹəfjuz sətʃ əz ju, bʌt sʌmwʌnz gɑnə noʊɾəs ju.' "

"I said it wouldn't work," said a hefty woman nearby. The woman rose and waddled down the line, wearing a tentlike dress of green and brown. " 'My Lady,' I told her, 'you can do as you wish, I ain't one to refuse such as you, but someone's going to notice you.' "

"jɔɹ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə wɑʃwɪmən," bɹaɪn sɛd.

"You're in charge of the washwomen," Bryne said.

ðə lɑɹdʒ wʊmən nɑɾəd fɝmli, hɝ ɹɛd kɝlz baʊnsɪŋ. "ɪndiɾ aɪ æm, dʒɛnɝəl." ʃi tɝn tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, kɝtsiɪŋ. "leɪɾi tɑɡɹɛn, aɪ dɪd wɔɹn ju. laɪt bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd. aɪm ɹaɪt sɑɹi."

The large woman nodded firmly, her red curls bouncing. "Indeed I am, General." She turned to the Aes Sedai, curtsying. "Lady Tagren, I did warn you. Light burn me, but I did. I'm right sorry."

ðə wʊmən kɔl tɑɡɹɛn baʊɾ əɹ hɛd. wɝ ðoʊz tɪɹz ɑn əɹ tʃiks? wɑz ðəɾ ivən pɑsəbəl? wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?

The woman called Tagren bowed her head. Were those tears on her cheeks? Was that even possible? What was going on?

"maɪ leɪɾi," bɹaɪn sɛd, skwɑɾɪŋ daʊn bɪsaɪd hɝ. "ɑɹ jə ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪf jə ɑɹ, ən jə kəmæn mi tə liv, əl də soʊ wɪθaʊt kwɛstʃən."

"My Lady," Bryne said, squatting down beside her. "Are you Aes Sedai? If you are, and you command me to leave, I will do so without question."

ə ɡʊd weɪ tə əpɹoʊtʃ ɪt. ɪf ʃi ɹɪli wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi kʊdn laɪ.

A good way to approach it. If she really was Aes Sedai, she couldn't lie.

"aɪm nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ," ðə wʊmən wɪspɝd.

"I'm not Aes Sedai," the woman whispered.

bɹaɪn lʊkt ʌp ət ɡɔɪn, fɹaʊnɪŋ. wʌɾ ɪt min ɪf ʃi sɛd ðæt? ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kʊdn laɪ. soʊ. . . .

Bryne looked up at Gawyn, frowning. What did it mean if she said that? An Aes Sedai couldn't lie. So. . . .

ðə wʊmən sɔfli sɛd, "maɪ neɪm ɪz ʃimɹɪn. aɪ wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, wʌns. bʌt noʊ mɔɹ. nɑt sɪns. . . ." ʃi lʊk daʊn əɡɛn. "pliz. dʒʌs liv mi tə wɝk ɪn maɪ ʃeɪm."

The woman softly said, "My name is Shemerin. I was Aes Sedai, once. But no more. Not since. . . ." She looked down again. "Please. Just leave me to work in my shame."

"aɪ wɪl," bɹaɪn sɛd. ðən i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "bʌɾ əl nid jə tə tɔk tə səm sɪstɝz fɹəm ðə kæmp fɝst. ðeɪɾ əv maɪ ɪɹz ɪf aɪ doʊn bɹɪŋ jə ɪn tə spik wɪð ðɛm."

"I will," Bryne said. Then he hesitated. "But I'll need you to talk to some sisters from the camp first. They'd have my ears if I don't bring you in to speak with them."

ðə wʊmən, ʃimɹɪn, saɪd bʌt stʊɾ ʌp.

The woman, Shemerin, sighed but stood up.

"kʌm ɑn," bɹaɪn sɛd tə ɡɔɪn. "aɪ hæv noʊ daʊt ðət ðəl ɔlsoʊ wɑnə tɔk tə ju. bɛs tə ɡɛt ðɪs oʊvɝ wɪð kwɪkli."

"Come on," Bryne said to Gawyn. "I have no doubt that they'll also want to talk to you. Best to get this over with quickly."

tʃæptɝ twɛntifaɪv

CHAPTER 25

ɪn dɑɹknəs ʃɛɹiəm pikt ɪndə hɝ dɑɹk tɛnt, hɛzɪɾənt, bʌt sɔ nʌθɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. əlaʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf ə smaɪl ə sæɾəsfækʃən, ʃi stɛpt ɪn ən dʒɹu ðə flæps kloʊzd. θɪŋz wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ kwaɪt wɛl, fəɹ wʌns.

In Darkness Sheriam peeked into her dark tent, hesitant, but saw nothing inside. Allowing herself a smile of satisfaction, she stepped in and drew the flaps closed. Things were going quite well, for once.

ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi stɪl tʃɛkt əɹ tɛn bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɛntɝd, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə wʌn u hæd səmtaɪmz lɝkt ɪnsaɪd. ðə wʌn hum ʃid nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə sɛns, jɛɾ ɔlweɪz fɛlt əz ðoʊ ʃi ʃʊd.

Of course, she still checked her tent before she entered, searching for the one who had sometimes lurked inside. The one whom she'd never been able to sense, yet always felt as though she should.

jɛs, ʃɛɹiəm stɪl tʃɛkt, ən pɹɑbli wəd fəɹ mʌnθs jɛt - bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid, naʊ. noʊ fæntəm weɪɾəd tə pʌnɪʃ hɝ.

Yes, Sheriam still checked, and probably would for months yet - but there was no need, now. No phantom waited to punish her.

ðə skwɛɹ lɪɾəl tɛnt wɑz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə stæn ʌp ɪn, wɪð ə kɑɾ əlɔŋ wʌn saɪɾ ən ə tʃɹʌŋk əlɔŋ ði ʌðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz dʒʌst ɹum fəɹ ə dɛsk, bʌɾ ɪt wəd soʊ kɹaʊd ðə speɪs ðət ʃid bɛɹli bi eɪbəl tə muv. bɪsaɪdz, ðəɹ wɑz ə pɝfəkli æksɛptəbəl dɛsk nɪɹbaɪ, ɪn ɛɡwinz ənjuz tɛnt.

The square little tent was large enough to stand up in, with a cot along one side and a trunk along the other. There was just room for a desk, but it would so crowd the space that she'd barely be able to move. Besides, there was a perfectly acceptable desk nearby, in Egwene's unused tent.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn tɔk ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ ðət tɛn tə sʌmwʌn ɛls - moʊst sɪstɝz hæd tə ʃɛɹ, ðoʊ mɔɹ tɛns wɝ biɪŋ bɹɔɾ ɪn itʃ wik. haʊɛvɝ, ði æmɪɝlɪnz tɛnt wɑz ə sɪmbəl. əz lɔŋ əz ðəɹ wɑz hoʊp ʌv ɛɡwinz ɹɪtɝn, hɝ tɛnt ʃəd weɪt fəɹ hɝ. ɪt wɑz kɛp nit baɪ ði ɪnkənsələbəl tʃɛsə, hum ʃɛɹiəm stɪl kɑt kɹaɪɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ mɪstʃɹəsəz kæptɪvəɾi. wɛl, soʊ lɔŋ əz ɛɡwin wɑz əweɪ, ðət tɛnt wɑz fʌŋkʃənəli ʃɛɹiəmz fəɹ ɔl bʌt slipɪŋ. æftɝ ɔl, ən æmɪɝlɪnz kipɝ wɑz ɪkspɛktəd tə lʊk æftɝ əɹ əfɛɹz.

There had been talk of giving that tent to someone else - most sisters had to share, though more tents were being brought in each week. However, the Amyrlin's tent was a symbol. As long as there was hope of Egwene's return, her tent should wait for her. It was kept neat by the inconsolable Chesa, whom Sheriam still caught crying about her mistress's captivity. Well, so long as Egwene was away, that tent was functionally Sheriam's for all but sleeping. After all, an Amyrlin's Keeper was expected to look after her affairs.

ʃɛɹiəm smaɪld əɡɛn, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn əɹ kɑt. nɑt lɔŋ əɡoʊ, hɝ laɪf hæd bɪn ə pɝpɛtʃuəl saɪkəl ə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ən peɪn. naʊ ðət wɑz oʊvɝ. blɛs ɹoʊmændə. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls ʃɛɹiəm θɔɾ ə ðə ful wʊmən, ɹoʊmændə hæd bɪn ðə wʌn tə tʃeɪs hɑlimə - ən ʃɛɹiəmz pʌnɪʃməns - aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp.

Sheriam smiled again, sitting down on her cot. Not long ago, her life had been a perpetual cycle of frustration and pain. Now that was over. Bless Romanda. Whatever else Sheriam thought of the fool woman, Romanda had been the one to chase Halima - and Sheriam's punishments - out of the camp.

peɪn wəd kʌm əɡɛn. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz æɡəni ən pʌnɪʃmən ɪnvɑlvd ɪn ðə sɝvəs ʃi ɡeɪv. bʌt ʃi hæd lɝn tə teɪk ðə taɪmz ə pis ən tʃɛɹɪʃ ðɛm.

Pain would come again. There was always agony and punishment involved in the service she gave. But she had learned to take the times of peace and cherish them.

ət taɪmz, ʃi wɪʃt ʃid kɛpt əɹ maʊθ kloʊzd, nɑɾ æskt kwɛstʃənz. bʌt ʃi hæd, ən hɪɹ ʃi wɑz. hɝ ælidʒiænsɪz hæd bɹɔɾ əɹ paʊɝ, əz pɹɑməst. bʌt noʊbɑdi hæd wɔɹn əɹ ə ðə peɪn.

At times, she wished she'd kept her mouth closed, not asked questions. But she had, and here she was. Her allegiances had brought her power, as promised. But nobody had warned her of the pain.

nɑɾ ɪnfɹikwənli ʃi wɪʃt ʃid tʃoʊzən ðə bɹaʊn ən hɪɾən hɝsɛlf əweɪ ɪn ə laɪbɹɛɹi sʌmwɛɹ, nɛvɝ tə si ʌðɝz. bʌt naʊ ʃi wɑz wɛɹ ʃi wɑz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ jus wʌndɝɪŋ əbaʊt wʌt kəɾ əv hæpənd.

Not infrequently she wished she'd chosen the Brown and hidden herself away in a library somewhere, never to see others. But now she was where she was. There was no use wondering about what could have happened.

ʃi saɪd, ðən ɹimuvd əɹ dʒɹɛs ən tʃeɪnʒd əɹ ʃɪft. ʃi dɪd soʊ ɪn ðə dɑɹk; kændəlz ən ɔɪl wɝ boʊθ ɹæʃənd, ən wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz' fʌnz dʒɹaɪɪŋ ʌp, ʃid nid tə haɪɾ əweɪ wʌt ʃi hæd fəɹ leɪɾɝ jus.

She sighed, then removed her dress and changed her shift. She did so in the dark; candles and oil were both rationed, and with the rebels' funds drying up, she'd need to hide away what she had for later use.

ʃi klaɪmd ɑntu ðə kɑt, pʊlɪŋ ʌp ðə blæŋkət. ʃi wɑzn soʊ naɪiv əz tə fil ɡɪlti əbaʊt ðə θɪŋz ʃid dʌn. ɛvɹi sɪstɝ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɛɾ əhɛd; ðæts wʌt laɪf wɑz əbaʊt!

She climbed onto the cot, pulling up the blanket. She wasn't so naive as to feel guilty about the things she'd done. Every sister in the White Tower tried to get ahead; that's what life was about!

ðəɹ wɑzn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wʊdn stæb əɹ sɪstɝz ɪn ðə bæk ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wəd ɡɪv əɹ ædvæntɪdʒ. ʃɛɹiəmz fɹɛnz wɝ dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ . . . pɹæktəst əɾ ɪt.

There wasn't an Aes Sedai who wouldn't stab her sisters in the back if she thought it would give her advantage. Sheriam's friends were just a little more . . . practiced at it.

bʌt waɪ hæd ði ɛn ə deɪz hæd tə kʌm naʊ ʌv ɔl taɪmz? ʌðɝz ɪn əɹ əsoʊsieɪʃən spoʊk ə ðə ɡlɔɹi ən ɡɹeɪɾ ɑnɝ ə biɪŋ əlaɪv ət ðɪs taɪm, bʌt ʃɛɹiəm dɪdn əɡɹi. ʃid dʒɔɪn tə ɹaɪz ɪn waɪt taʊɝ pɑlətɪks, tə hæv ðə paʊɝ tə pʌnɪʃ ðoʊz u spəɾɪd hɝ. ʃid nɛvɝ wɑntəd tə pɑɹtɪsəpeɪɾ ɪn səm faɪnəl ɹɛkənɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ʃid sɝɾənli nɛvɝ dɪzaɪɝd tə hæv ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə tʃoʊzən!

But why had the end of days had to come now of all times? Others in her association spoke of the glory and great honor of being alive at this time, but Sheriam didn't agree. She'd joined to rise in White Tower politics, to have the power to punish those who spited her. She'd never wanted to participate in some final reckoning with the Dragon Reborn, and she'd certainly never desired to have anything to do with the Chosen!

bʌt nʌθɪŋ kəd bi dʌn naʊ. bɛs tə ɛndʒɔɪ ðə pis ə biɪŋ fɹi ʌv boʊθ ðə biɾɪŋz ən ɛɡwinz sɛlf-ɹaɪtʃəs pɹeɪɾɪŋz. jɛs ɪndid. . . .

But nothing could be done now. Best to enjoy the peace of being free of both the beatings and Egwene's self-righteous pratings. Yes indeed. . . .

ðəɹ wɑz ə wʊmən wɪð ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ əɹ tɛnt.

There was a woman with great strength in the Power standing outside her tent.

ʃɛɹiəm snæpt əɹ aɪz oʊpən. ʃi kəd sɛns ʌðɝ wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl, dʒʌs laɪk ɛni ʌðɝ sɪstɝ. blʌɾi æʃəz! ʃi θɔt nɝvəsli, skwizɪŋ əɹ aɪz ʃʌt. nɑɾ əɡɛn!

Sheriam snapped her eyes open. She could sense other women who could channel, just like any other sister. Bloody ashes! she thought nervously, squeezing her eyes shut. Not again!

ðə tɛn flæps ɹɪpəld. ʃɛɹiəm oʊpən əɹ aɪz tə faɪn ə dʒɛt-blæk fɪɡjɝ stændɪŋ əbʌv əɹ kɑt;

The tent flaps rippled. Sheriam opened her eyes to find a jet-black figure standing above her cot;

slɪvɝz ə munlaɪt pæsɪŋ θɹu ðə flʌɾɝɪŋ tɛn flæps wɝ dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə aʊtlaɪn ðə fɪɡjɝz fɔɹm. ɪt wɑz kloʊðd ɪn ən ənnætʃɹəl dɑɹknəs, ɹɪbənz ə blæk klɔθ flʌɾɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪt, ðə feɪs əbskjʊɹd baɪ ə dip blæknəs. ʃɛɹiəm ɡæspt ən θɹu hɝsɛlf fɹəm ðə kɑt, meɪkɪŋ oʊbaɪsəns ɑn ðə kænvəs tɛn bɑɾəm. ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɹum ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə nil. ʃi kɹɪnʒd, ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðə peɪn tə kʌm əpɑn əɹ əɡɛn.

slivers of moonlight passing through the fluttering tent flaps were just enough to outline the figure's form. It was clothed in an unnatural darkness, ribbons of black cloth fluttering behind it, the face obscured by a deep blackness. Sheriam gasped and threw herself from the cot, making obeisance on the canvas tent bottom. There was barely room enough for her to kneel. She cringed, expecting the pain to come upon her again.

"ɑ . . ." ə ɹæspɪŋ vɔɪs sɛd. "vɛɹi ɡʊd. jə ɑɹ oʊbiɾiənt. aɪm plizd."

"Ah . . ." a rasping voice said. "Very good. You are obedient. I am pleased."

ɪt wɑzn hɑlimə. ʃɛɹiəm hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə sɛns hɑlimə, hu ɪɾ əpɪɹd hæd bɪn tʃænəlɪŋ seɪɾɪn ɔl əlɔŋ. ɔlsoʊ, hɑlimə hæd nɛvɝ kʌm ɪn sətʃ ə . . . dʒɹəmæɾɪk weɪ.

It wasn't Halima. Sheriam had never been able to sense Halima, who it appeared had been channeling saidin all along. Also, Halima had never come in such a . . . dramatic way.

sətʃ stʃɹɛŋkθ! ɪt sim laɪkli ðət ðɪs wɑz wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən. iðɝ ðæt, əɹ ət list ə vɛɹi paʊɝfəl sɝvən ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, fɑɹ əbʌv ʃɛɹiəm. ðət wɝiɾ əɹ tə ðə boʊn, ən ʃi tʃɹɛmbəld əz ʃi baʊd. "aɪ lɪv tə sɝv, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd kwɪkli. "aɪ, hu æm blɛsɪd tə baʊ bɪfɔɹ ju, tə lɪv dʊɹɪŋ ðiz taɪmz, tə - "

Such strength! It seemed likely that this was one of the Chosen. Either that, or at least a very powerful servant of the Great Lord, far above Sheriam. That worried her to the bone, and she trembled as she bowed. "I live to serve, Great Mistress," Sheriam said quickly. "I, who am blessed to bow before you, to live during these times, to - "

"stɑp jəɹ bæbəlɪŋ," ðə vɔɪs ɡɹaʊld. "ju ɑɹ wɛl pleɪst ɪn ðɪs kæmp, aɪ ʌndɝstænd?"

"Stop your babbling," the voice growled. "You are well placed in this camp, I understand?"

"jɛs, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd. "aɪ æm ðə kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz."

"Yes, Great Mistress," Sheriam said. "I am the Keeper of the Chronicles."

ðə fɪɡjɝ snɪft. "kipɝ tə ə ɹæɡəd bʌntʃ ʌv wʊd-bi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɛbəlz. bʌt ðəɾ ɪz noʊ mæɾɝ. aɪ hæv niɾ ə ju."

The figure sniffed. "Keeper to a ragged bunch of would-be Aes Sedai rebels. But that is no matter. I have need of you."

"aɪ lɪv tə sɝv, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ʃɛɹiəm ɹɪpiɾɪd, ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ wɝid. wʌd ðɪs kɹitʃɝ wɑn ə hɝ?

"I live to serve, Great Mistress," Sheriam repeated, growing more worried. What did this creature want of her?

"ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ. ʃi mʌs bi dɪpoʊzd."

"Egwene al'Vere. She must be deposed."

"wʌt?" ʃɛɹiəm æskt, stɑɹɾəld. ə swɪtʃ ʌv ɛɹ kɹækt əɡɛnst əɹ bæk, ən ɪt bɝnd. ful!

"What?" Sheriam asked, startled. A switch of Air cracked against her back, and it burned. Fool!

dɪd ʃi wɑnə ɡɛt hɝsɛlf kɪld? "maɪ əpɑlədʒiz, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ʃi sɛd kwɪkli. "fɝɡɪv maɪ aʊtbɝst. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz baɪ ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən ðəɾ aɪ hɛlpt ɹeɪz əɹ əz æmɪɝlɪn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs!"

Did she want to get herself killed? "My apologies, Great Mistress," she said quickly. "Forgive my outburst. But it was by orders from one of the Chosen that I helped raise her as Amyrlin in the first place!"

"jɛs, bʌt ʃiz pɹuvən tə hæv bɪn ə . . . pʊɹ tʃɔɪs. wi niɾəd ə tʃaɪld, nɑɾ ə wʊmən wɪð mɪɹli ðə feɪs ʌv ə tʃaɪld. ʃi mʌs bi ɹimuvd. jəl meɪk sɝɾən ðɪs ɡɹup ə fulɪʃ ɹɛbəlz stɑps səpɔɹɾɪŋ hɝ. ən ɛn ðoʊz blæstəd miɾɪŋz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. haʊ ɪz ɪt soʊ mɛni ʌv jə ɡɛt ðɛɹ?"

"Yes, but she has proven to have been a . . . poor choice. We needed a child, not a woman with merely the face of a child. She must be removed. You will make certain this group of foolish rebels stops supporting her. And end those blasted meetings in Tel'aran'rhiod. How is it so many of you get there?"

"wi hæv tɛɹæŋɡɹil," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd, hɛzɪɾəntli. "sɛvɹəl ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ən æmbɝ plæk, sɛvɹəl ʌðɝz ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ən aɪɝn dɪsk. ðən ə hændfʊl ə ɹɪŋz."

"We have ter'angreal," Sheriam said, hesitantly. "Several in the shape of an amber plaque, several others in the shape of an iron disc. Then a handful of rings."

"ɑ, slipwivɝz," ðə fɪɡjɝ sɛd. "jɛs, ðoʊz kəd bi jusfəl. haʊ mɛni?"

"Ah, sleepweavers," the figure said. "Yes, those could be useful. How many?"

ʃɛɹiəm hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hɝ fɝst ɪnstɪŋkt wɑz tə laɪ əɹ hɛdʒ - ðɪs sim laɪk ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ʃi kəd hoʊld oʊvɝ ðə fɪɡjɝ. bʌt laɪɪŋ tə wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən? ə pʊɹ tʃɔɪs. "wi hæd twɛnti," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd tʃɹuθfəli. "bʌt wʌn wɑz wɪð ðə wʊmən lin, hu wɑz kæptʃɝd. ðət livz əs wɪð naɪntin."

Sheriam hesitated. Her first instinct was to lie or hedge - this seemed like information she could hold over the figure. But lying to one of the Chosen? A poor choice. "We had twenty," Sheriam said truthfully. "But one was with the woman Leane, who was captured. That leaves us with nineteen."

dʒʌst ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛɡwinz miɾɪŋz ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz - wʌn fəɹ itʃ ə ðə sɪɾɝz ən wʌn fəɹ ʃɛɹiəm hɝsɛlf.

Just enough for Egwene's meetings in the World of Dreams - one for each of the Sitters and one for Sheriam herself.

"jɛs," ðə fɪɡjɝ hɪst, ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn dɑɹknəs. "jusfəl ɪndid. stil ðə slipwivɝz, ðən ɡɪv əm tə mi. ðɪs ɹæbəl əz noʊ bɪznəs tʃɹɛɾɪŋ wɛɹ ðə tʃoʊzən wɔk."

"Yes," the figure hissed, shrouded in darkness. "Useful indeed. Steal the sleepweavers, then give them to me. This rabble has no business treading where the Chosen walk."

"aɪ. . . ." stil ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil? haʊ wɑz ʃi gɑnə mænədʒ ðæt? "aɪ lɪv tə sɝv, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs."

"I. . . ." Steal the ter'angreal? How was she going to manage that? "I live to serve, Great Mistress."

"jɛs jə du. də ðiz θɪŋz fəɹ mi, ən jəl faɪn jɝsɛlf ɡɹeɪtli ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd. feɪl mi. . . ."

"Yes you do. Do these things for me, and you will find yourself greatly rewarded. Fail me. . . ."

ðə fɪɡjɝ kɑntəmpleɪɾɪd fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "ju hæv θɹi deɪz. itʃ ə ðə slipwivɝz jə feɪl tə əkwaɪɝ ɪn ðət taɪm wɪl kɑs jə ə fɪŋɡɝ əɹ ə toʊ." wɪð ðæt, ðə tʃoʊzən oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum, ðən vænɪʃt θɹu ɪt. ʃɛɹiəm kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə ðə fəmɪljɝ taɪl hɔlweɪz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd.

The figure contemplated for a moment. "You have three days. Each of the sleepweavers you fail to acquire in that time will cost you a finger or a toe." With that, the Chosen opened a gateway right in the middle of the room, then vanished through it. Sheriam caught a glimpse of the familiar tiled hallways of the White Tower on the other side.

stil ðə slipwivɝz! ɔl naɪntin ə ðɛm? ɪn θɹi deɪz? dɑɹknəs əbʌv! ʃɛɹiəm θɔt. aɪ ʃʊɾə laɪɾ əbaʊt ðə nʌmbɝ wi hæd! waɪ dɪdn aɪ laɪ?

Steal the sleepweavers! All nineteen of them? In three days? Darkness above! Sheriam thought. I should have lied about the number we had! Why didn't I lie?

ʃi ɹɪmeɪnd nilɪŋ, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊt, fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ pɹɪdɪkəmənt. hɝ pɪɹiəɾ ə pis wɑz əɾ ən ɛnd, ɪɾ əpɪɹd.

She remained kneeling, breathing in and out, for a long time, thinking about her predicament. Her period of peace was at an end, it appeared.

ɪt hæd bɪn bɹif.

It had been brief.

"ʃi wɪl bi tʃɹaɪd, ʌv kɔɹs," sin sɛd. ðə sɑft-spoʊkən waɪt sæɾ ɑn ə tʃɛɹ pɹəvaɪɾəd fəɹ əɹ baɪ ðə tu ɹɛdz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɛɡwinz sɛl.

"She will be tried, of course," Seaine said. The soft-spoken White sat on a chair provided for her by the two Reds guarding Egwene's cell.

ðə sɛl dɔɹ wɑz oʊpən, ən ɛɡwin sæɾ ɑn ə stul ɪnsaɪd - ɔlsoʊ pɹəvaɪɾəd baɪ ðə ɹɛdz. ðoʊz tu ɡɑɹdz, plʌmp kɑɹiɑndɝ ən stɝn peɪtʃɹində, wɑtʃt kɛɹfəli fɹəm ðə hɔlweɪ, boʊθ hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹs ən meɪnteɪnɪŋ ɛɡwinz ʃild. ðeɪ lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə dɑɹɾ əweɪ, skɹæmbəlɪŋ fəɹ fɹiɾəm.

The cell door was open, and Egwene sat on a stool inside - also provided by the Reds. Those two guards, plump Cariandre and stern Patrinda, watched carefully from the hallway, both holding the Source and maintaining Egwene's shield. They looked as if they expected her to dart away, scrambling for freedom.

ɛɡwin ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. hɝ tu deɪz ʌv ɪmpɹɪzənmən hæd nɑt bɪn plɛzənt, bʌt ʃi wəd sʌfɝ əm wɪð dɪɡnəɾi. ivən ɪf ðeɪ lɑkt əɹ əweɪ ɪn ə taɪni ɹum wɪð ə dɔɹ ðət wʊdn lɛɾ ɪn laɪt.

Egwene ignored them. Her two days of imprisonment had not been pleasant, but she would suffer them with dignity. Even if they locked her away in a tiny room with a door that wouldn't let in light.

ivən ɪf ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ əɹ tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm ðə blʌɾid nɑvəs dʒɹɛs. ivən ɪf ðeɪ biɾ əɹ itʃ deɪ fəɹ haʊ ʃi hæd tʃɹiɾəd ɪleɪɾə. ɛɡwin wəd nɑt baʊ.

Even if they refused to let her change from the bloodied novice dress. Even if they beat her each day for how she had treated Elaida. Egwene would not bow.

ðə ɹɛdz ɹɪlʌktənli əlaʊɾ əɹ vɪzəɾɝz, əz stɪpjəleɪɾɪd baɪ taʊɝ lɔ. ɛɡwin wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ʃi hæd vɪzəɾɝz, bʌt sin wɑzn ði oʊnli wʌn u hæd kʌm tə hɝ. sɛvɹəl hæd bɪn sɪɾɝz.

The Reds reluctantly allowed her visitors, as stipulated by Tower law. Egwene was surprised she had visitors, but Seaine wasn't the only one who had come to her. Several had been Sitters.

kjʊɹiəs. nɛvɝðəlɛs, ɛɡwin wɑz stɑɹv fəɹ nuz. haʊ wɑz ðə taʊɝ ɹiæktɪŋ tə ɛɡwinz ɪmpɹɪzənmənt? wɝ ðə ɹɪfs bɪtwin ði ədʒəz stɪl dip ən waɪd, əɹ hæɾ əɹ wɝk stɑɹɾəd tə bɹɪdʒ ðɛm?

Curious. Nevertheless, Egwene was starved for news. How was the Tower reacting to Egwene's imprisonment? Were the rifts between the Ajahs still deep and wide, or had her work started to bridge them?

"ɪleɪɾə bɹoʊk taʊɝ lɔ kwaɪɾ ɪksplɪsətli," sin ɪkspleɪnd. "æn ɪt wɑz wɪtnəs baɪ faɪv sɪɾɝz ə faɪv dɪfɹən ədʒəz. ʃiz tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹstɔl ə tʃɹaɪəl, bʌt wɑz ʌnsəksɛsfəl. haʊɛvɝ, ðəɹ wɝ səm u lɪsən tə hɝ ɑɹɡjəmənt."

"Elaida broke Tower law quite explicitly," Seaine explained. "And it was witnessed by five Sitters of five different Ajahs. She has tried to forestall a trial, but was unsuccessful. However, there were some who listened to her argument."

"wɪtʃ wɑz?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"Which was?" Egwene asked.

"ðæt jə ɑɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd," sin sɛd. "ænd, kəz ʌv ɪt, ʃi ɪkspɛl jə fɹəm ðə taʊɝ, ən ðən bit ju."

"That you are a Darkfriend," Seaine said. "And, because of it, she expelled you from the Tower, and then beat you."

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə tʃɪl. ɪf ɪleɪɾə wɑz eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ ɪnʌf səpɔɹt fəɹ ðəɾ ɑɹɡjəmənt. . . .

Egwene felt a chill. If Elaida was able to get enough support for that argument. . . .

"ɪt wɪl nɑt stænd," sin sɛd, kənsoʊlɪŋli. "ðɪs ɪz nɑt səm bækwɝd vɪlədʒ, wɛɹ ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ skɹɔld ɑn sʌmwʌnz dɔɹ ɪz ɪnʌf tə kənvɪkt."

"It will not stand," Seaine said, consolingly. "This is not some backward village, where the Dragon's Fang scrawled on someone's door is enough to convict."

ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. ʃid bɪn ɹeɪzd ɪn "sʌm bækwɝd vɪlədʒ," ən ðeɪd hæɾ ɪnʌf sɛns tə lʊk fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ɹumɝz ɪn kənvɪktɪŋ sʌmwʌn, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə kɹaɪm. bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Egwene raised an eyebrow. She'd been raised in "some backward village," and they'd had enough sense to look for more than rumors in convicting someone, no matter what the crime. But she said nothing.

"pɹuvɪŋ ðəɾ ækjəzeɪʃən ɪz dɪfəkəl baɪ taʊɝ stændɝdz," sin sɛd. "æn soʊ aɪ səspɛk ðət ʃɪl nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə pɹuv ɪɾ ɪn tʃɹaɪəl - pɑɹʃəli kəz duɪŋ soʊ wəd ɹikwaɪɝ əɹ tə lɛt jə spik fəɹ jɝsɛlf, ən aɪ səspɛk ðət ʃɪl wɑnə kip jə hɪɾən."

"Proving that accusation is difficult by Tower standards," Seaine said. "And so I suspect that she will not try to prove it in trial - partially because doing so would require her to let you speak for yourself, and I suspect that she'll want to keep you hidden."

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd, aɪɪŋ ðə ɹɛdz laʊnʒɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ. "ju ɑɹ pɹɑbli ɹaɪt. bʌɾ ɪf ʃi kæn pɹuv ɪm ə dɑɹkfɹɛn ən ʃi kʊdn stɑp ðɪs fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ tə tʃɹaɪəl . . ."

"Yes," Egwene said, eyeing the Reds lounging nearby. "You are probably right. But if she can't prove I'm a Darkfriend and she couldn't stop this from going to trial . . ."

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑɾ ən əfɛns wɝði ʌv dəpoʊzɪŋ hɝ," sin sɛd. "ðə mæksəməm pʌnɪʃmən ɪz fɔɹməl sɛnʃɝ fɹəm ðə hɔl ən pɛnəns fəɹ ə mʌnθ. ʃi wəd ɹɪteɪn ðə ʃɔl."

"It is not an offense worthy of deposing her," Seaine said. "The maximum punishment is formal censure from the Hall and penance for a month. She would retain the shawl."

bʌt wəd luz ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə kɹɛɾəbɪlɪti, ɛɡwin θɔt. ɪt wɑz ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ. bʌt haʊ tə meɪk sɝɾən ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə dɪdn dʒʌs haɪɾ əɹ əweɪ? ʃi hæd tə kip ðə pɹɛʃɝ ɑn ɪleɪɾə - laɪt-kɝs dɪfəkəlt waɪl lɑkt əweɪ ɪn əɹ taɪni sɛl itʃ deɪ! ɪt hæd bɪn oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt taɪm soʊ fɑɹ, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ðə lɔst ɑpɝtunəɾiz ɡɹeɪɾɪd ɑn hɝ.

But would lose a great deal of credibility, Egwene thought. It was encouraging. But how to make certain that Elaida didn't just hide her away? She had to keep the pressure on Elaida - Light-cursed difficult while locked away in her tiny cell each day! It had been only a short time so far, but already the lost opportunities grated on her.

"ju wɪl ətɛn ðə tʃɹaɪəl?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"You will attend the trial?" Egwene asked.

"ʌv kɔɹs," sin sɛd, ivən-tɛmpɝd, əz ɛɡwin hæd kʌm tə ɪkspɛk fɹəm ðə waɪt. səm waɪts wɝ ɔl kulnəs ən lɑdʒɪk. sin wɑz mʌtʃ wɔɹmɝ ðən ðæt, bʌt wɑz stɪl vɛɹi ɹɪzɝvd.

"Of course," Seaine said, even-tempered, as Egwene had come to expect from the White. Some Whites were all coolness and logic. Seaine was much warmer than that, but was still very reserved.

"aɪ æm ə sɪɾɝ, ɛɡwin."

"I am a Sitter, Egwene."

"aɪ əsum ðət jəɹ stɪl siɪŋ ði ɪfɛks ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz stɝɪŋ?" ɛɡwin ʃɪvɝɾ ən ɡlænst əɾ əɹ sɛl flɔɹ, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌt hæd hæpən tə lin. hɝ oʊn sɛl wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ɔstɪɹ ðən linz, pɝhæps kəz ə ði ækjəzeɪʃənz ə hɝ biɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd.

"I assume that you're still seeing the effects of the Dark One's stirring?" Egwene shivered and glanced at her cell floor, remembering what had happened to Leane. Her own cell was far more austere than Leane's, perhaps because of the accusations of her being a Darkfriend.

"jɛs." sinz vɔɪs ɡɹu sɑftɝ. "ðeɪ sim tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ wɝs. sɝvəns daɪɪŋ. fud spɔɪlɪŋ. ɪntaɪɝ sɛkʃənz ə ðə taʊɝ ɹiɝeɪnʒɪŋ ət ɹændəm. ðə sɛkən kɪtʃən muv tə ðə sɪksθ lɛvəl læs naɪt, muvɪŋ ən ɪntaɪɝ sɛkʃən ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝz ɪndə ðə beɪsmənt. ɪts laɪk wʌt hæpənd wɪð ðə bɹaʊnz ɝliɝ, ən ðət wʌn stɪl hæzən bɪn wɝkt aʊt."

"Yes." Seaine's voice grew softer. "They seem to be getting worse. Servants dying. Food spoiling. Entire sections of the Tower rearranging at random. The second kitchen moved to the sixth level last night, moving an entire section of the Yellow Ajah quarters into the basement. It's like what happened with the Browns earlier, and that one still hasn't been worked out."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. wɪð ðə weɪ ðə ɹumz hæd ʃɪftəd, ðoʊz fju nɑvəsɪz huz ɹumz hædn muv sʌɾənli naʊ hæɾ əsaɪn əkɑmədeɪʃənz ɑn ðə twɛnti-fɝst ən twɛnti-sɛkən lɛvəlz, wɛɹ bɹaʊn ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn. ðə bɹaʊnz wɝ, ɹɪlʌktənli, ɔl muvɪŋ daʊn tə ðə wɪŋ.

Egwene nodded. With the way the rooms had shifted, those few novices whose rooms hadn't moved suddenly now had assigned accommodations on the twenty-first and twenty-second levels, where Brown Ajah quarters had been. The Browns were, reluctantly, all moving down to the wing.

wəɾ ɪt bi ə pɝmənən tʃeɪnʒ? ɔlweɪz bɪfɔɹ, ðə sɪstɝz hæd lɪvd ɪn ðə taʊɝ pɹɑpɝ, ðə nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd lɪvɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪŋ.

Would it be a permanent change? Always before, the sisters had lived in the Tower proper, the novices and Accepted living in the wing.

"ju hæv tə bɹɪŋ ðiz θɪŋz ʌp, sin," ɛɡwin sɛd sɔfli. "kip ɹimaɪndɪŋ ðə sɪstɝz ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn stɝz ən ðət ðə læs bæɾəl əpɹoʊtʃɪz. kip ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən ɑn wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, nɑt dɪvaɪɾɪŋ."

"You have to bring these things up, Seaine," Egwene said softly. "Keep reminding the sisters that the Dark One stirs and that the Last Battle approaches. Keep their attention on working together, not dividing."

bɪhaɪn sin, wʌn ə ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz tʃɛk ðə kændəl ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ðə taɪm əlɑɾɪd fəɹ ɛɡwin tə ɹəsiv vɪzəɾɝz wɑz ɛndɪŋ. ʃid sun bi lɑkt əweɪ əɡɛn; ʃi kəd smɛl ðə dʌsti, əntʃeɪnʒd stʃɹɔ bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Behind Seaine, one of the Red sisters checked the candle on the table. The time allotted for Egwene to receive visitors was ending. She'd soon be locked away again; she could smell the dusty, unchanged straw behind her.

"ju mʌst wɝk hɑɹd, sin," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ əz ðə ɹɛdz əpɹoʊtʃt. "du wʌɾ aɪ kænɑt.

"You must work hard, Seaine," Egwene said, rising as the Reds approached. "Do what I cannot.

æsk ði ʌðɝz tə də soʊ əz wɛl."

Ask the others to do so as well."

"aɪ wɪl tʃɹaɪ," sin sɛd. ʃi stʊɾ ən wɑtʃt əz ðə ɹɛdz tʊk ɛɡwinz stul, ðən dʒɛstʃɝɾ əɹ bæk ɪndə ðə sɛl. ðə silɪŋ wɑz tu loʊ fəɹ əɹ tə stænd wɪθaʊt stupɪŋ.

"I will try," Seaine said. She stood and watched as the Reds took Egwene's stool, then gestured her back into the cell. The ceiling was too low for her to stand without stooping.

ɛɡwin muvd ɹɪlʌktənli, bɛndɪŋ daʊn. "ðə læs bæɾəl kʌmz, sin. ɹɪmɛmbɝ."

Egwene moved reluctantly, bending down. "The Last Battle comes, Seaine. Remember."

ðə waɪt nɑɾəd, ən ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt, lɑkɪŋ ɛɡwin ɪndə dɑɹknəs. ɛɡwin sæt daʊn. ʃi fɛl soʊ blaɪnd! wʌt wəd hæpən ət ðə tʃɹaɪəl? ivən ɪf ɪleɪɾə wɑz pʌnɪʃt, wʌt wəd bi dʌn wɪð ɛɡwin?

The White nodded, and the door shut, locking Egwene into darkness. Egwene sat down. She felt so blind! What would happen at the trial? Even if Elaida was punished, what would be done with Egwene?

ɪleɪɾə wəd tʃɹaɪ tə hæv əɹ ɛksəkjuɾəd. ən ʃi stɪl hæd ɡɹaʊnz, əz ɛɡwin hæd - baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝz dɛfənɪʃən - ɪmpɝsəneɪɾɪd ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

Elaida would try to have her executed. And she still had grounds, as Egwene had - by the White Tower's definition - impersonated the Amyrlin Seat.

aɪ mʌst steɪ fɝm, ɛɡwin toʊl hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. aɪ wɔɹm ðɪs pɑt maɪsɛlf, ən naʊ aɪ mʌs bɔɪl ɪn ɪt, ɪf ðəɾ ɪz wʌt wɪl pɹətɛk ðə taʊɝ. ðeɪ nu ʃi kəntɪnjud tə ɹɪzɪst. ðət wɑz ɔl ʃi kəd ɡɪv ðɛm.

I must stay firm, Egwene told herself in the darkness. I warmed this pot myself, and now I must boil in it, if that is what will protect the Tower. They knew she continued to resist. That was all she could give them.

tʃæptɝ twɛntisɪks

CHAPTER 26

eɪ kɹæk ɪn ðə stoʊn eɪvinhə sɝveɪd ðə mænɝ ɡɹaʊnz, swɔɹmɪŋ wɪð pipəl pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə dɪpɑɹt. bæʃɪɹz mɛn ən wɪmən wɝ wɛl tʃɹeɪn fəɹ wɛtləndɝz, ən ðeɪ wɝkt ɪfɪʃənli tə stoʊ ðɛɹ tɛns ən pɹipɛɹ ðɛɹ ɡɪɹ. haʊɛvɝ, kəmpɛɹd tə ði il, ði ʌðɝ wɛtləndɝz - ðoʊz u wɝn æktʃəwəl soʊlʒɝz - wɝ ə mɛs. kæmp wɪmən skɪɾɝd ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt, əz ɪf ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəd liv səm tæsk əndʌn əɹ səm aɪɾəm ənpækt. ðə mɛsənʒɝ bɔɪz ɹæn wɪð ðɛɹ fɹɛnz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk bɪzi soʊ ðət ðeɪ wʊdn əv tə də ɛniθɪŋ. ðə səvɪljənz' tɛns ən ɪkwɪpmənt wɝ oʊnli sloʊli biɪŋ pækt ən stoʊd, ən ðeɪ wəd nid hɔɹsəz, wæɡənz ən timz ə dʒɹaɪvɝz tə ɡɛɾ əm ɔl wɛɹ ðeɪ niɾəd tə ɡoʊ.

A Crack in the Stone Aviendha surveyed the manor grounds, swarming with people preparing to depart. Bashere's men and women were well trained for wetlanders, and they worked efficiently to stow their tents and prepare their gear. However, compared to the Aiel, the other wetlanders - those who weren't actual soldiers - were a mess. Camp women skittered this way and that, as if sure they would leave some task undone or some item unpacked. The messenger boys ran with their friends, trying to look busy so that they wouldn't have to do anything. The civilians' tents and equipment were only slowly being packed and stowed, and they would need horses, wagons and teams of drivers to get them all where they needed to go.

eɪvinhə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ði il bɹɔɾ oʊnli wʌt ðeɪ kəd kæɹi, ən ðɛɹ wɔɹ bæn ɪnkluɾəd oʊnli spɪɹz ən waɪz wʌnz. ən wən mɔɹ ðən dʒʌst spɪɹz wɝ ɹikwaɪɝd fəɹ ən ɪkstɛndəd kæmpeɪn, ɔl wɝkɝz ən kɹæftspipəl nu haʊ tə pɹipɛɹ ðɛmsɛlvz fəɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ wɪð spiɾ ən ɪfɪʃənsi. ðəɹ wɑz ɑnɝ ɪn ðæt. ɑnɝ wɪtʃ dɪmændəd ðəɾ itʃ pɝsən bi eɪbəl tə kɛɹ fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz ən ðɛɹ oʊn, nɑt sloʊɪŋ ðə klæn daʊn.

Aviendha shook her head. The Aiel brought only what they could carry, and their war band included only spears and Wise Ones. And when more than just spears were required for an extended campaign, all workers and craftspeople knew how to prepare themselves for departure with speed and efficiency. There was honor in that. Honor which demanded that each person be able to care for themselves and their own, not slowing the clan down.

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə hɝ tæsk. ði oʊnli wʌnz u tʃɹuli lækt ɑnɝ ɑn ə deɪ laɪk ðɪs wɝ ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt wɝk. ʃi dɪpt ə fɪŋɡɝ ɪndə ðə peɪl ʌv wɔɾɝ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ðən ɹeɪzd əɹ hæn ən lɛɾ ɪt hʌvɝ oʊvɝ ə sɛkən peɪl. ə dʒɹɑp ʌv wɔɾɝ dʒɹɪp fɹi. ʃi muvd əɹ hæn ən dɪɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn.

She shook her head, turning back to her task. The only ones who truly lacked honor on a day like this were those who did not work. She dipped a finger into the pail of water on the ground in front of her, then raised her hand and let it hover over a second pail. A drop of water dripped free. She moved her hand and did it again.

ɪt wɑz ðə taɪp ə pʌnɪʃmən ɪn wɪtʃ noʊ wɛtləndɝ cʊɾə sin səɡnɪfɪkəns. ðeɪ wʊɾə θɔɾ ɪɾ izi wɝk, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, linɪŋ wɪð əɹ bæk əɡɛns ðə wʊɾən lɔɡz ə ðə mænɝ haʊs. muvɪŋ əɹ hæn bæk ən fɔɹθ, ɛmptiɪŋ wʌn peɪl ən fɪlɪŋ ði ʌðɝ, wʌn dʒɹɑp əɾ ə taɪm. tə ðɛm ɪt wʊɾə bɪn bɛɹli ə pʌnɪʃmən əɾ ɔl.

It was the type of punishment in which no wetlander could have seen significance. They would have thought it easy work, sitting on the ground, leaning with her back against the wooden logs of the manor house. Moving her hand back and forth, emptying one pail and filling the other, one drop at a time. To them it would have been barely a punishment at all.

ðət wɑz kəz wɛtləndɝz wɝ ɔfən leɪzi. ðeɪ wəd ɹæðɝ dʒɹɪp wɔɾɝ ɪndə peɪlz ðən kæɹi ɹɑks. kæɹiɪŋ ɹɑks, haʊɛvɝ, ɪnvɑlvd æktɪvəɾi - ən æktɪvəɾi wɑz ɡʊd fəɹ ðə maɪn ən ðə bɑɾi.

That was because wetlanders were often lazy. They would rather drip water into pails than carry rocks. Carrying rocks, however, involved activity - and activity was good for the mind and the body.

muvɪŋ wɔɾɝ wɑz minɪŋləs. jusləs. ɪt dɪdn əlaʊ hɝ tə stʃɹɛtʃ əɹ lɛɡz əɹ wɝk əɹ mʌsəlz.

Moving water was meaningless. Useless. It didn't allow her to stretch her legs or work her muscles.

ən ʃi dɪɾ ɪt waɪl ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kæmp ɡæðɝd tɛns fəɹ ðə mɑɹtʃ. ðət meɪd ðə pʌnɪʃmən tɛn taɪmz əz ʃeɪmfəl! ʃi ɝn toʊ fəɹ ɛvɹi moʊmənt ʃi dɪd nɑt hɛlp, ən ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə θɪŋ ʃi kəd də əbaʊɾ ɪt.

And she did it while the rest of the camp gathered tents for the march. That made the punishment ten times as shameful! She earned toh for every moment she did not help, and there was not a thing she could do about it.

ɪksɛp muv wɔɾɝ. dʒɹɪp, baɪ dʒɹɪp, baɪ dʒɹɪp.

Except move water. Drip, by drip, by drip.

ɪt meɪɾ əɹ æŋɡɹi. ðən ðəɾ æŋɡɝ meɪɾ əɹ əʃeɪmd. ðə waɪz wʌnz nɛvɝ lɛt ðɛɹ ɪmoʊʃənz dɑməneɪɾ əm ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ. ʃi hæd tə ɹɪmeɪn peɪʃən ən tʃɹaɪ tə ʌndɝstænd waɪ ʃi wɑz biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt.

It made her angry. Then that anger made her ashamed. The Wise Ones never let their emotions dominate them in such a way. She had to remain patient and try to understand why she was being punished.

ivən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðə pɹɑbləm meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə skɹim. haʊ mɛni taɪmz kəd ʃi ɡoʊ oʊvɝ ðə seɪm kənkluʒənz ɪn əɹ maɪnd? pɝhæps ʃi wɑz tu dɛns tə sɔɹɾ ɪɾ aʊt. pɝhæps ʃi dɪdn dɪzɝv tə bi ə waɪz wʌn.

Even trying to approach the problem made her want to scream. How many times could she go over the same conclusions in her mind? Perhaps she was too dense to sort it out. Perhaps she didn't deserve to be a Wise One.

ʃi stʌk əɹ hæn bæk ɪn ðə bʌkət, ðən muvd ənʌðɝ dʒɹɑp ʌv wɔɾɝ. ʃi dɪdn laɪk wʌt ðiz pʌnɪʃməns wɝ duɪŋ tə hɝ. ʃi wɑz ə wɔɹiɝ, ivən ɪf ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kæɹid ðə spɪɹ. ʃi dɪd nɑt fɪɹ pʌnɪʃmənt, nɔɹ dɪd ʃi fɪɹ peɪn. bʌt, mɔɹ ən mɔɹ, ʃi dɪd fɪɹ ðət ʃi wəd luz hɑɹɾ ən bɪkʌm əz jusləs əz wʌn u sændstɛɹd.

She stuck her hand back in the bucket, then moved another drop of water. She didn't like what these punishments were doing to her. She was a warrior, even if she no longer carried the spear. She did not fear punishment, nor did she fear pain. But, more and more, she did fear that she would lose heart and become as useless as one who sandstared.

ʃi wɑntəd tə bɪkʌm ə waɪz wʌn, wɑntəɾ ɪt dɛspɝətli. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðæt, fəɹ ʃid nɛvɝ θɔt ðət ʃi kəd dɪzaɪɝ ɛniθɪŋ wɪð əz mʌtʃ pæʃən əz ʃid lɔŋ əɡoʊ wɑntəd ðə spɪɹz. jɛɾ əz ʃi hæd stʌɾid ðə waɪz wʌnz dʊɹɪŋ ðiz læs mʌnθs, ən əɹ ɹɪspɛk fəɹ əm hæd ɡɹoʊn, ʃi hæɾ æksɛptɪd hɝsɛlf əz ðɛɹ ikwəl, tə hɛlp ʃɛpɝd ði il ɪn ðɪs moʊs deɪnʒɝəs ə deɪz.

She wanted to become a Wise One, wanted it desperately. She was surprised to find that, for she'd never thought that she could desire anything with as much passion as she'd long ago wanted the spears. Yet as she had studied the Wise Ones during these last months, and her respect for them had grown, she had accepted herself as their equal, to help shepherd the Aiel in this most dangerous of days.

ðə læs bæɾəl wəd bi ə tɛst ənlaɪk ɛni hɝ pipəl hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn. æmɪz ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ wɝkɪŋ tə pɹətɛk ði il, ən eɪvinhə sæɾ ən muv dʒɹɑps ʌv wɔɾɝ!

The Last Battle would be a test unlike any her people had ever known. Amys and the others were working to protect the Aiel, and Aviendha sat and moved drops of water!

"ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?" ə vɔɪs æskt.

"Are you all right?" a voice asked.

eɪvinhə stɑɹɾəd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ əɹ naɪf soʊ əbɹʌpli ðət ʃi nɪɹli spɪl ðə peɪlz ʌv wɔɾɝ. ə wʊmən wɪð ʃɔɹt, dɑɹk hɛɹ stʊɾ ɪn ðə ʃeɪɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ. mɪn fɑɹʃɔz ɑɹmz wɝ foʊldəɾ ən ʃi wɔɹ ə koʊt ðə kʌlɝ ə koʊbɔlt wɪð sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. ʃi wɔɹ ə skɑɹf əɾ əɹ nɛk.

Aviendha started, looking up, reaching for her knife so abruptly that she nearly spilled the pails of water. A woman with short, dark hair stood in the shade of the building a short distance away. Min Farshaw's arms were folded and she wore a coat the color of cobalt with silver embroidery. She wore a scarf at her neck.

eɪvinhə sɛɾəld bæk daʊn, ɹilisɪŋ əɹ naɪf. naʊ ʃi wɑz lɛɾɪŋ wɛtləndɝz snik ʌp ɑn hɝ? "aɪ æm wɛl," ʃi sɛd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kip fɹəm blʌʃɪŋ.

Aviendha settled back down, releasing her knife. Now she was letting wetlanders sneak up on her? "I am well," she said, struggling to keep from blushing.

hɝ toʊn ən ækʃənz ʃʊɾə ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət ʃi dɪdnt wɪʃ tə bi ʃeɪm baɪ kɑnvɝseɪʃən, bʌt mɪn dɪdn sim tə noʊɾəs ðæt. ðə wʊmən tɝn ən lʊkt aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə kæmp. "doʊnt . . . juv ɛniθɪŋ tə bi duɪŋ?"

Her tone and actions should have indicated that she didn't wish to be shamed by conversation, but Min didn't seem to notice that. The woman turned and looked out over the camp. "Don't . . . you have anything to be doing?"

eɪvinhə kəd nɑt səpɹɛs ðə blʌʃ ðɪs taɪm. "aɪ æm duɪŋ wʌɾ aɪ ʃʊd."

Aviendha could not suppress the blush this time. "I am doing what I should."

mɪn nɑɾəd, ən eɪvinhə fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə stɪl əɹ bɹiðɪŋ. ʃi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə ɡɹoʊ æŋɡɹi ət ðɪs wʊmən. hɝ fɝst-sɪstɝ hæɾ æskt əɹ tə bi kaɪn tə mɪn. ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd nɑt tə teɪk əfɛns.

Min nodded, and Aviendha forced herself to still her breathing. She could not afford to grow angry at this woman. Her first-sister had asked her to be kind to Min. She decided not to take offense.

mɪn dɪdnt noʊ wʌt ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ.

Min didn't know what she was saying.

"aɪ θɔt ðəɾ aɪ kəd tɔk tə ju," mɪn sɛd, stɪl lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ət ðə kæmp. "aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ u ɛls aɪ kəɾ əpɹoʊtʃ. aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌs ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən niðɝ dʌz hi. aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ i tʃɹʌsts ɛniwʌn, naʊ.

"I thought that I could talk to you," Min said, still looking out at the camp. "I'm not sure who else I could approach. I don't trust the Aes Sedai, and neither does he. I'm not sure he trusts anyone, now.

meɪbi nɑɾ ivən mi."

Maybe not even me."

eɪvinhə ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd, ən sɔ ðət mɪn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd ælθɹ əz i muv θɹu ðə kæmp, wɛɹɪŋ ə koʊɾ ə blæk, ɡoʊld-ɹɛd hɛɹ əbleɪz ɪn ði æftɝnun laɪt. hi sim tə taʊɝ oʊvɝ ðə sɑldəiənz u ətɛndəd hɪm.

Aviendha glanced to the side, and saw that Min was watching Rand al'Thor as he moved through the camp, wearing a coat of black, gold-red hair ablaze in the afternoon light. He seemed to tower over the Saldaeans who attended him.

eɪvinhə hæd hɝɾ əbaʊt ði ɪvɛns ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ, wən i hæd bɪn ətæk baɪ sɛmɝhɪdʒ.

Aviendha had heard about the events the night before, when he had been attacked by Semirhage.

wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld ðɛmsɛlvz; eɪvinhə wɪʃt ʃi hæd sin ðə kɹitʃɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz kɪld. ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd.

One of the Shadowsouled themselves; Aviendha wished she had seen the creature before she was killed. She shuddered.

ɹænd ælθɹ hæd fɔɾ ən wʌn. ðoʊ hi æktəd ðə ful mʌtʃ ə ðə taɪm, hi wɑz ə skɪld -  ən lʌki - wɔɹiɝ. hu ɛls əlaɪv kəd kleɪm tə hæv pɝsənəli dɪfiɾəd əz mɛni ʌv ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld əz i hæd? ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ ɑnɝ ɪn hɪm.

Rand al'Thor had fought and won. Though he acted the fool much of the time, he was a skilled -  and lucky - warrior. Who else alive could claim to have personally defeated as many of the Shadowsouled as he had? There was much honor in him.

hɪz faɪt hæd lɛft ɪm skɑɹɾ ɪn weɪz ʃi dɪd nɑt jɛɾ ʌndɝstænd. ʃi kəd fil ɪz peɪn. ʃid fɛlt ɪt dʊɹɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒəz ətæk, tu, ðoʊ ət fɝst ʃid mɪsteɪkənli θɔɾ ɪt tə bi ə naɪtmɛɹ.

His fight had left him scarred in ways she did not yet understand. She could feel his pain. She'd felt it during Semirhage's attack, too, though at first she'd mistakenly thought it to be a nightmare.

ʃid kwɪkli ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz ɹɔŋ. noʊ naɪtmɛɹ kəd bi ðət tɛɹəbəl. ʃi kəd stɪl fil ɛkoʊz ə ðəɾ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl peɪn, ðoʊz weɪvz ʌv æɡəni, ðə fɹɛnzi ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm.

She'd quickly realized that she was wrong. No nightmare could be that terrible. She could still feel echoes of that incredible pain, those waves of agony, the frenzy inside of him.

eɪvinhə hæd ɹeɪz ði əlɑɹm, bʌt nɑt kwɪkli ɪnʌf. ʃi hæd toʊ tə hɪm fəɹ əɹ mɪsteɪk; ʃi wəd dil wɪð ðət wʌns ʃi wɑz fɪnɪʃt wɪð əɹ pʌnɪʃməns. ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ dɪd fɪnɪʃ.

Aviendha had raised the alarm, but not quickly enough. She had toh to him for her mistake; she would deal with that once she was finished with her punishments. If she ever did finish.

"ɹæn ælθɹ wɪl dil wɪð ɪz pɹɑbləmz," ʃi sɛd, dʒɹɪpɪŋ mɔɹ wɔɾɝ.

"Rand al'Thor will deal with his problems," she said, dripping more water.

"haʊ kən jə seɪ ðæt?" mɪn æskt, ɡlænsɪŋ ət hɝ. "kæn jə fil ɪz peɪn?"

"How can you say that?" Min asked, glancing at her. "Can't you feel his pain?"

"aɪ fil itʃ ən ɛvɹi moʊmən ʌv ɪt," eɪvinhə sɛd θɹu ɡɹɪɾɪd tiθ. "bʌɾ i mʌs feɪs ɪz oʊn tʃɹaɪəlz, dʒʌst əz aɪ feɪs maɪn. pɝhæps ðəɹ wɪl bi ə deɪ wən i ən aɪ kən feɪs aʊɝz təɡɛðɝ, bʌt ðət taɪm ɪz nɑt naʊ."

"I feel each and every moment of it," Aviendha said through gritted teeth. "But he must face his own trials, just as I face mine. Perhaps there will be a day when he and I can face ours together, but that time is not now."

aɪ mʌs bi hɪz ikwəl, fɝst, ʃi æɾəd ɪn əɹ hɛd. əl nɑt stæn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm əz ɪz ɪnfɪɹiɝ.

I must be his equal, first, she added in her head. I will not stand beside him as his inferior.

mɪn stʌɾid hɝ, ən eɪvinhə fɛlt ə tʃɪl, wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt vɪʒənz ðə wʊmən sɔ. hɝ pɹidɪkʃənz ə ðə fjutʃɝ wɝ sɛɾ ɔlweɪz tə kʌm tʃɹu.

Min studied her, and Aviendha felt a chill, wondering what visions the woman saw. Her predictions of the future were said always to come true.

"ju ɑɹ nɑt wʌɾ aɪ ɪkspɛktəd," mɪn faɪnəli sɛd.

"You are not what I expected," Min finally said.

"aɪ hæv dɪsiv ju?" eɪvinhə sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"I have deceived you?" Aviendha said, frowning.

"noʊ, nɑt ðæt," mɪn sɛd wɪð ə smɔl læf. "aɪ min, aɪ wɑz ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ju, aɪ ɡɛs. aɪ wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt tə θɪŋk, æftɝ ðət naɪɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn wən . . . wɛl, ðət naɪt wən wi bɑndəd ɹænd təɡɛðɝ. aɪ fil kloʊs tə ju, jɛt dɪstən fɹəm jə ət ðə seɪm taɪm." ʃi ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ ɡɛs aɪ ɪkspɛktəd jə tə kʌm lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi ðə moʊmən jə ɡɑɾ ɪndə kæmp. wi hæd θɪŋz tə dɪskʌs. wən jə dɪdnt, aɪ wɝid. aɪ θɔt pɝhæps aɪ hæɾ əfɛndəd ju."

"No, not that," Min said with a small laugh. "I mean, I was wrong about you, I guess. I wasn't certain what to think, after that night in Caemlyn when . . . well, that night when we bonded Rand together. I feel close to you, yet distant from you at the same time." She shrugged. "I guess I expected you to come looking for me the moment you got into camp. We had things to discuss. When you didn't, I worried. I thought perhaps I had offended you."

"ju hæv noʊ toʊ tə mi," eɪvinhə sɛd.

"You have no toh to me," Aviendha said.

"ɡʊd," mɪn sɛd. "aɪ stɪl wɝi səmtaɪmz ðət wɪl . . . kʌm tə ə kɑnfɹənteɪʃən."

"Good," Min said. "I still worry sometimes that we'll . . . come to a confrontation."

"ænd wʌt ɡʊd wəɾ ə kɑnfɹənteɪʃən sɝv?"

"And what good would a confrontation serve?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," mɪn sɛd wɪð ə ʃɹʌɡ. "aɪ fɪɡjɝɾ ɪt wəd bi ði il weɪ. tʃælənʒ mi tə ə faɪɾ ʌv ɑnɝ. fəɹ hɪm."

"I don't know," Min said with a shrug. "I figured it would be the Aiel way. Challenge me to a fight of honor. For him."

eɪvinhə snɔɹɾɪd. "faɪɾ oʊvɝ ə mæn? hu wəd də sətʃ ə θɪŋ? ɪf jə hæd toʊ təwɔɹd mi, pɝhæps aɪ kəd dɪmæn ðət wi dæns ðə spɪɹz - bʌɾ oʊnli ɪf jə wɝ ə meɪɾən. ən oʊnli ɪf aɪ wɝ stɪl wʌn tu. aɪ səpoʊz ðət wi kəd faɪt wɪð naɪvz, bʌɾ ɪt wəd hɑɹdli bi ə fɛɹ faɪt. wʌɾ ɑnɝ wəd ðəɹ tə bi ɡeɪn ɪn faɪɾɪŋ wʌn wɪð noʊ skɪl?"

Aviendha snorted. "Fight over a man? Who would do such a thing? If you had toh toward me, perhaps I could demand that we dance the spears - but only if you were a Maiden. And only if I were still one too. I suppose that we could fight with knives, but it would hardly be a fair fight. What honor would there to be gained in fighting one with no skill?"

mɪn flʌʃt, əz ɪf eɪvinhə hæɾ ɔfɝɾ əɹ ən ɪnsəlt. wʌɾ ə kjʊɹiəs ɹiækʃən. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt ðæt," mɪn sɛd, flɪpɪŋ ə naɪf fɹəm əɹ sliv ən spɪnɪŋ ɪɾ əkɹɔs əɹ nʌkəlz. "aɪm hɑɹdli dɪfɛnsləs." ʃi meɪd ðə naɪf vænɪʃ ʌp əɹ ʌðɝ sliv. waɪ wɑz ɪt ðət ðə wɛtləndɝz ɔlweɪz ʃoʊɾ ɔf sətʃ flɝɪʃəz wɪð ðɛɹ naɪvz? tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn hæd bɪn pɹoʊn tə ðəɾ əz wɛl. dɪdn mɪn ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ eɪvinhə cʊɾə slɪt ðə wʊmənz θɹoʊt θɹaɪs oʊvɝ dʊɹɪŋ ðə taɪm ɪt tʊk tə flæʃ ðət naɪf laɪk ə stʃɹit pɝfɔɹmɝ? eɪvinhə sɛd nʌθɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ. mɪn wɑz ɑbviəsli pɹaʊɾ ə ðə skɪl, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə ɪmbɛɹəs ðə wʊmən.

Min flushed, as if Aviendha had offered her an insult. What a curious reaction. "I don't know about that," Min said, flipping a knife from her sleeve and spinning it across her knuckles. "I'm hardly defenseless." She made the knife vanish up her other sleeve. Why was it that the wetlanders always showed off such flourishes with their knives? Thom Merrilin had been prone to that as well. Didn't Min understand that Aviendha could have slit the woman's throat thrice over during the time it took to flash that knife like a street performer? Aviendha said nothing, however. Min was obviously proud of the skill, and there was no need to embarrass the woman.

"ɪɾ ɪz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt," eɪvinhə sɛd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ əɹ wɝk. "aɪ wəd nɑt faɪt wɪð jə ənlɛs jə ɡeɪv mi ɡɹeɪv ɪnsəlt. maɪ fɝst-sɪstɝ kənsɪɾɝz jə ə fɹɛnd, ən aɪ wəd laɪk tə də soʊ əz wɛl."

"It is unimportant," Aviendha said, continuing her work. "I would not fight with you unless you gave me grave insult. My first-sister considers you a friend, and I would like to do so as well."

"ɔl ɹaɪt," mɪn sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ən lʊkɪŋ bæk ət ɹænd. "wɛl, aɪ ɡɛs ðæts ə ɡʊd θɪŋ. aɪ hæv tə ədmɪt, aɪ doʊn mʌtʃ laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv ʃɛɹɪŋ."

"All right," Min said, folding her arms and looking back at Rand. "Well, I guess that's a good thing. I have to admit, I don't much like the idea of sharing."

eɪvinhə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən dɪpt əɹ fɪŋɡɝ ɪndə ðə peɪl. "niðɝ də aɪ." ət list, ʃi dɪdn laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv ʃɛɹɪŋ wɪð ə wʊmən ʃi dɪdnt noʊ vɛɹi wɛl.

Aviendha hesitated, then dipped her finger into the pail. "Neither do I." At least, she didn't like the idea of sharing with a woman she didn't know very well.

"ðɛn wʌt də wi du?"

"Then what do we do?"

"wi kəntɪnju əz wi hæv," eɪvinhə sɛd. "ju hæv wʌt jə wɪʃ, ən aɪm ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ ʌðɝ mæɾɝz. wən ɪt bɪkʌmz ə dɪfɹən taɪm, əl ɪnfɔɹm ju."

"We continue as we have," Aviendha said. "You have what you wish, and I am occupied by other matters. When it becomes a different time, I will inform you."

"ðæts . . . stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝɾ ə ju," mɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ kənfjuzd. "ju hæv ʌðɝ mæɾɝz tə ɑkjəpaɪ ju? laɪk dɪpɪŋ jəɹ fɪŋɡɝ ɪn bʌkəts ʌv wɔɾɝ?"

"That's . . . straightforward of you," Min said, looking confused. "You have other matters to occupy you? Like dipping your finger in buckets of water?"

eɪvinhə blʌʃt əɡɛn. "jɛs," ʃi snæpt. "dʒʌs laɪk ðæt. jəl ɪkskjuz mi." ʃi stʊɾ ən stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ, livɪŋ ðə bʌkəts. ʃi nu ðət ʃi ʃəd nɑɾ əv lɔst əɹ tɛmpɝ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp ɪt. mɪn, ɹɪpiɾɪdli pɔɪntɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ pʌnɪʃmənt. hɝ ɪnəbɪlɪɾi tə dɪsaɪfɝ wʌt ðə waɪz wʌnz wɪʃt ə hɝ. ɹænd ælθɹ, kɑnstənli pʊɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪndə deɪnʒɝ, ən eɪvinhə əneɪbəl tə lɪft ə fɪŋɡɝ tə hɛlp hɪm.

Aviendha blushed again. "Yes," she snapped. "Just like that. You will excuse me." She stood and strode away, leaving the buckets. She knew that she should not have lost her temper, but she could not help it. Min, repeatedly pointing out her punishment. Her inability to decipher what the Wise Ones wished of her. Rand al'Thor, constantly putting himself into danger, and Aviendha unable to lift a finger to help him.

ʃi kəd stæn ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. ʃi kɹɔs ðə bɹaʊn θætʃ ə ðə mænɝ ɡɹin, klɛntʃɪŋ ən ənklɛntʃɪŋ əɹ fɪsts, kipɪŋ əɹ dɪstəns fɹəm ɹænd. ðə weɪ ðɪs deɪ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, hid noʊɾəs əɹ ɹɪŋkəl fɪŋɡɝ ən æsk waɪ ʃi hæd bɪn soʊkɪŋ ɪt! ɪf i dɪskʌvɝd ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd bɪn pʌnɪʃɪŋ hɝ, hi wəd pɹɑbli də sʌmθɪŋ ɹæʃ ən meɪk ə ful ə hɪmsɛlf. mɛn wɝ laɪk ðæt, ɹænd ælθɹ moʊst ʌv ɔl.

She could stand it no longer. She crossed the brown thatch of the manor green, clenching and unclenching her fists, keeping her distance from Rand. The way this day was going, he'd notice her wrinkled finger and ask why she had been soaking it! If he discovered that the Wise Ones had been punishing her, he would probably do something rash and make a fool of himself. Men were like that, Rand al'Thor most of all.

ʃi stɔkt əkɹɔs ðə spɹɪŋi ɡɹaʊnd, ðə bɹaʊn θætʃ pæɾɝnd wɪð skwɛɹ ɪmpɹɛʃənz wɛɹ tɛns hæd stʊd, θɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ weɪ θɹu wɛtləndɝz skɝiɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt. ʃi pæst ə laɪn ə soʊlʒɝz tɔsɪŋ sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn tə ðə nɛkst ən loʊɾɪŋ əm ɪn ə wæɡən hɪtʃt tə tu θɪk-hʊf dʒɹæf hɔɹsəz.

She stalked across the springy ground, the brown thatch patterned with square impressions where tents had stood, threading her way through wetlanders scurrying this way and that. She passed a line of soldiers tossing sacks of grain to the next and loading them in a wagon hitched to two thick-hoofed draft horses.

ʃi kɛp muvɪŋ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip hɝsɛlf fɹəm ɪksploʊɾɪŋ. ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, ʃi fɛl dʒʌst əz laɪkli tə də sʌmθɪŋ "ɹæʃ" əz ɹænd ælθɹ wəd bi. waɪ? waɪ kʊdnt ʃi dɪsaɪfɝ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ɹɔŋ? ði ʌðɝ il ɪn ðə kæmp simd əz ɪɡnɝən əz ʃi, ðoʊ ʌv kɔɹs ðeɪ hæd nɑt spoʊkən tə hɝ ə ðə pʌnɪʃməns. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd wɛl siɪŋ sɪməlɝ pʌnɪʃməns wən ʃid bɪn ə meɪɾən, ən hæɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn tə steɪ aʊɾ ʌv waɪz wʌnz' bɪznəs.

She kept moving, trying to keep herself from exploding. The truth was, she felt just as likely to do something "rash" as Rand al'Thor would be. Why? Why couldn't she decipher what she was doing wrong? The other Aiel in the camp seemed as ignorant as she, though of course they had not spoken to her of the punishments. She remembered well seeing similar punishments when she'd been a Maiden, and had always known to stay out of Wise Ones' business.

ʃi ɹaʊndəd ðə wæɡən, ən faʊn hɝsɛlf hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ɹænd ælθɹ əɡɛn. hi wɑz tɔkɪŋ wɪð θɹi ʌv dævɹæm bæʃɪɹz kɔɹɾɝmæstɝz, tɔlɝ ðən itʃ ə ðɛm baɪ ə hɛd. wʌn ə ðɛm, ə mæn wɪð ə lɔŋ blæk mʌstæʃ, pɔɪntəd təwɔɹd ðə hɔɹslaɪnz ən sɛd sʌmθɪŋ. ɹænd kɑt saɪɾ ʌv eɪvinhə ən ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn təwɔɹd hɝ, bʌt ʃi tɝn əweɪ kwɪkli, muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ði il kæmpsaɪɾ ət ðə nɔɹθ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹin.

She rounded the wagon, and found herself heading toward Rand al'Thor again. He was talking with three of Davram Bashere's quartermasters, taller than each of them by a head. One of them, a man with a long black mustache, pointed toward the horselines and said something. Rand caught sight of Aviendha and raised his hand toward her, but she turned away quickly, moving toward the Aiel campsite at the north side of the green.

ʃi ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ - ʌnsəksɛsfəli - tə teɪm əɹ æŋɡɝ. dɪd ʃi nɑɾ əv ə ɹaɪt tə æŋɡɝ, ɪf oʊnli ət hɝsɛlf? ðə wɝld wɑz kloʊs tə ɛndɪŋ ən ʃi spɛn əɹ deɪz biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt!

She ground her teeth, trying - unsuccessfully - to tame her anger. Did she not have a right to anger, if only at herself? The world was close to ending and she spent her days being punished!

əhɛd, ʃi spɑɾəd ə smɔl klʌstɝ ʌv waɪz wʌnz - æmɪz, bɛɹ ən məleɪn - stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə paɪl ə bɹaʊn tɛn pæks. ðə taɪt, ɑblɔŋ bʌndəlz hæd stʃɹæps fəɹ iz ə kæɹiɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ʃoʊldɝ.

Ahead, she spotted a small cluster of Wise Ones - Amys, Bair and Melaine - standing beside a pile of brown tent packs. The tight, oblong bundles had straps for ease of carrying over the shoulder.

eɪvinhə ʃʊɾə ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ peɪlz ən ɹidʌbəld əɹ ɛfɝts. bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt. laɪk ə tʃaɪld wɪð ə stɪk tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ə nɑɹʃkæt, ʃi stɔkt ʌp tə ðə waɪz wʌnz, fjumɪŋ.

Aviendha should have returned to her pails and redoubled her efforts. But she did not. Like a child with a stick charging a narshcat, she stalked up to the Wise Ones, fuming.

"eɪvinhə?" bɛɹ æskt. "hæv jə fɪnɪʃt jəɹ pʌnɪʃmən ɔlɹɛɾi?"

"Aviendha?" Bair asked. "Have you finished your punishment already?"

"noʊ aɪ hæv nɑt," eɪvinhə sɛd, stɑpɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm, hænz fɪsts əɾ əɹ saɪdz. wɪn tʌɡd əɾ əɹ ʃɝt, bʌt ʃi lɛɾ ɪt flæp. hɝiɪŋ kæmp wɝkɝz - boʊθ il ən sɑldəiən - ɡeɪv ðə ɡɹup ə waɪd bɝθ.

"No I have not," Aviendha said, stopping in front of them, hands fists at her sides. Wind tugged at her shirt, but she let it flap. Hurrying camp workers - both Aiel and Saldaean - gave the group a wide berth.

"wɛl?" bɛɹ æskt.

"Well?" Bair asked.

"ju ɑɹ nɑt lɝnɪŋ kwɪkli ɪnʌf," æmɪz æɾəd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ waɪt-hɛɹd hɛd.

"You are not learning quickly enough," Amys added, shaking her white-haired head.

"nɑt lɝnɪŋ kwɪkli ɪnʌf?" eɪvinhə dɪmændəd. "aɪ hæv lɝn ɛvɹiθɪŋ juv æskt ə mi! aɪ hæv mɛmɝaɪzd ɛvɹi lɛsən, ɹɪpiɾɪd ɛvɹi fækt, pɝfɔɹmd ɛvɹi duɾi. aɪ hæv ænsɝɾ ɔl jəɹ kwɛstʃənz ən əv sin jə nɑɾ ɪn əpɹuvəl əɾ itʃ ænsɝ!"

"Not learning quickly enough?" Aviendha demanded. "I have learned everything you have asked of me! I have memorized every lesson, repeated every fact, performed every duty. I have answered all your questions and have seen you nod in approval at each answer!"

ʃi stɛɹɾ əm daʊn bɪfɔɹ kəntɪnjuɪŋ. "aɪ kən tʃænəl bɛɾɝ ðən ɛni il wʊmən əlaɪv," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ hæv lɛf bɪhaɪn ðə spɪɹz, ən aɪ wɛlkəm maɪ pleɪs əmʌŋ ju. aɪ hæv dʌn maɪ duɾi ən sɔɾ ɑnɝ ɑn itʃ əkeɪʒən. jɛt jə kəntɪnju tə ɡɪmi pʌnɪʃməns! əl əv noʊ mɔɹ ʌv ɪt.

She stared them down before continuing. "I can channel better than any Aiel woman alive," she said. "I have left behind the spears, and I welcome my place among you. I have done my duty and sought honor on each occasion. Yet you continue to give me punishments! I will have no more of it.

iðɝ tɛl mi wʌɾ ɪts jə wɪʃ ə mi əɹ sɛn mi əweɪ."

Either tell me what it is you wish of me or send me away."

ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ æŋɡɝ fɹəm ðɛm. ʃi ɪkspɛktəd dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ ə mɪɹ əpɹɛntəs wɑz nɑt tə kwɛstʃən fʊl waɪz wʌnz. ʃi ɪkspɛktəd, ət list, tə bi ɡɪvən ɡɹeɪɾɝ pʌnɪʃmən fəɹ əɹ təmɛɹəɾi.

She expected anger from them. She expected disappointment. She expected them to explain that a mere apprentice was not to question full Wise Ones. She expected, at least, to be given greater punishment for her temerity.

æmɪz ɡlænst ət məleɪn ən bɛɹ. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt wi hu pʌnɪʃ ju, tʃaɪld," ʃi sɛd, simɪŋ tə tʃuz əɹ wɝdz wɪð kɛɹ. "ðiz pʌnɪʃməns kʌm baɪ jəɹ oʊn hænd."

Amys glanced at Melaine and Bair. "It is not we who punish you, child," she said, seeming to choose her words with care. "These punishments come by your own hand."

"wʌtɛvɝ aɪ hæv dʌn," eɪvinhə sɛd, "aɪ kænɑt si ðəɾ ɪt wəɾ əv jə meɪk mi dætsæŋ.

"Whatever I have done," Aviendha said, "I cannot see that it would have you make me da'tsang.

jə ʃeɪm jʊɹsɛlvz baɪ tʃɹiɾɪŋ mi soʊ."

You shame yourselves by treating me so."

"tʃaɪld," æmɪz sɛd, miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz. "ɑɹ jə ɹɪdʒɛktɪŋ əɹ pʌnɪʃməns?"

"Child," Amys said, meeting her eyes. "Are you rejecting our punishments?"

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd, hɑɹt θʌmpɪŋ. "aɪ æm."

"Yes," she said, heart thumping. "I am."

"ju θɪŋk jəɹ steɪks əz stʃɹɔŋ əz aʊɝz, də ju?" bɛɹ æskt, ʃeɪɾɪŋ əɹ eɪdʒ feɪs wɪð əɹ hænd. "ju pɹɪzum tə bi əɹ ikwəl?"

"You think your stakes as strong as ours, do you?" Bair asked, shading her aged face with her hand. "You presume to be our equal?"

ðɛɹ ikwəl? eɪvinhə θɔt, pænɪk sɛɾɪŋ ɪn. aɪm nɑt ðɛɹ ikwəl! aɪ hæv jɪɹz lɛf tə stʌɾi.

Their equal? Aviendha thought, panic setting in. I'm not their equal! I have years left to study.

wʌɾ æm aɪ duɪŋ?

What am I doing?

kəd ʃi bæk daʊn naʊ? bɛɡ fɝɡɪvnəs, miɾ əɹ toʊ sʌmhaʊ? ʃi ʃəd hɝi bæk tə hɝ pʌnɪʃmən ən muv ðə wɔɾɝz. jɛs! ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ʃi niɾəd tə du. ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ ən -  "aɪ si noʊ mɔɹ ɹizən tə stʌɾi," ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf seɪɪŋ ɪnstɛd. "ɪf ðiz pʌnɪʃməns ɑɹ ɔl juv lɛf tə titʃ mi, ðən aɪ mʌst əsum ðəɾ aɪ hæv lɝn ɔl ðəɾ aɪ mʌst. aɪm ɹɛɾi tə dʒɔɪn ju."

Could she back down now? Beg forgiveness, meet her toh somehow? She should hurry back to her punishment and move the waters. Yes! That is what she needed to do. She had to go and -  "I see no more reason to study," she found herself saying instead. "If these punishments are all you have left to teach me, then I must assume that I have learned all that I must. I am ready to join you."

ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ɪksploʊʒən ə fjʊɹiəs ɪnkɹədulɪɾi. wʌt wɑz ʃi θɪŋkɪŋ? ʃi ʃʊdn əv lɛt mɪnz fulɪʃ tɔk ɹaɪl əɹ soʊ.

She gritted her teeth, waiting for an explosion of furious incredulity. What was she thinking? She shouldn't have let Min's foolish talk rile her so.

ən ðən bɛɹ stɑɹɾəd tə læf.

And then Bair started to laugh.

ɪt wɑz ə fʊl-bɛlid saʊnd, ɪŋkɔŋɹuəs kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə smɔl wʊmən. məleɪn dʒɔɪn hɝ, ðə sʌn-hɛɹd waɪz wʌn hoʊldɪŋ əɹ stʌmək, slaɪtli bʌlʒɪŋ fɹəm əɹ pɹɛɡnənsi. "ʃi tʊk ivən lɔŋɡɝ ðən ju, æmɪz!" məleɪn ɪkskleɪmd. "æz stʌbɝn ə ɡɝl əz aɪv ɛvɝ sin."

It was a full-bellied sound, incongruous coming from the small woman. Melaine joined her, the sun-haired Wise One holding her stomach, slightly bulging from her pregnancy. "She took even longer than you, Amys!" Melaine exclaimed. "As stubborn a girl as I've ever seen."
