æmɪz' ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz ʌnkɛɹɪktɝɪstɪkli sɑft. "wɛlkəm, sɪstɝ," ʃi sɛd tə eɪvinhə.

Amys' expression was uncharacteristically soft. "Welcome, sister," she said to Aviendha.

eɪvinhə blɪŋkt. "wʌt?"

Aviendha blinked. "What?"

"ju ɑɹ wʌn ʌv əs naʊ, ɡɝl!" bɛɹ sɛd. "ɔɹ sun wɪl bi."

"You are one of us now, girl!" Bair said. "Or soon will be."

"bʌɾ aɪ dɪfaɪd ju!"

"But I defied you!"

"eɪ waɪz wʌn kænɑɾ əlaʊ ʌðɝz tə stɛp əpɑn hɝ," æmɪz sɛd. "ɪf ʃi kʌmz ɪndə ðə ʃeɪɾ ʌv əɹ sɪstɝhʊd θɪŋkɪŋ laɪk ən əpɹɛntəs, ðən ʃɪl nɛvɝ si hɝsɛlf əz wʌn ʌv ʌs."

"A Wise One cannot allow others to step upon her," Amys said. "If she comes into the shade of our sisterhood thinking like an apprentice, then she will never see herself as one of us."

bɛɹ ɡlænst ət ɹænd ælθɹ, hu stʊɾ ɪn ðə dɪstəns tɔkɪŋ tə sɝin. "aɪ nɛvɝ ɹilaɪz haʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt əɹ weɪz wɝ əntɪl aɪ stʌɾid ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðoʊz ət ðə bɑɾəm sɪmpɝ ən bɛɡ laɪk haʊnz, ən ɑɹ ɪɡnɔɹd baɪ ðoʊz u kənsɪɾɝ ðɛmsɛlvz ðɛɹ bɛɾɝz. ɪts ə wʌndɝ ðeɪ ətʃiv ɛniθɪŋ!"

Bair glanced at Rand al'Thor, who stood in the distance talking to Sarene. "I never realized how important our ways were until I studied these Aes Sedai. Those at the bottom simper and beg like hounds, and are ignored by those who consider themselves their betters. It is a wonder they achieve anything!"

"bʌt ðəɹ ɪz ɹæŋk əmʌŋ waɪz wʌnz," eɪvinhə sɛd. "ɪz ðəɹ nɑt?"

"But there is rank among Wise Ones," Aviendha said. "Is there not?"

"ɹæŋk?" æmɪz lʊk pʌzəld. "sʌm ʌv əs əv mɔɹ ɑnɝ ðən ʌðɝz, ɝn baɪ wɪzdəm, ækʃənz ən ɪkspɪɹiəns."

"Rank?" Amys looked puzzled. "Some of us have more honor than others, earned by wisdom, actions and experience."

məleɪn hɛld ʌp ə fɪŋɡɝ. "bʌɾ ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt -  vaɪɾəl, ivən - ðəɾ itʃ waɪz wʌn bi wɪlɪŋ tə dɪfɛn əɹ oʊn wɛl. ɪf ʃi bɪlivz ðət ʃiz ɹaɪt, ʃi kænɑt lɛt hɝsɛlf bi ʃʌvd əsaɪd, ivən baɪ ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ eɪdʒɪɾ əɹ waɪz."

Melaine held up a finger. "But it is important -  vital, even - that each Wise One be willing to defend her own well. If she believes that she is right, she cannot let herself be shoved aside, even by other Wise Ones, no matter how aged or wise."

"noʊ wʊmən ɪz ɹɛɾi tə dʒɔɪn əs əntɪl ʃiz dɪklɛɹd hɝsɛlf ɹɛɾi," æmɪz kəntɪnjud. "ʃi mʌs pɹizɛn hɝsɛlf əz əɹ ikwəl."

"No woman is ready to join us until she has declared herself ready," Amys continued. "She must present herself as our equal."

"ə pʌnɪʃmən ɪz nɑɾ ə tʃɹu pʌnɪʃmən ənlɛs jə æksɛpt ɪt, eɪvinhə," bɛɹ sɛd, stɪl smaɪlɪŋ.

"A punishment is not a true punishment unless you accept it, Aviendha," Bair said, still smiling.

"wi θɔt jə ɹɛɾi wiks əɡoʊ, bʌt jə stʌbɝnli kəntɪnjud tə oʊbeɪ."

"We thought you ready weeks ago, but you stubbornly continued to obey."

"ɔlmoʊst, aɪ bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk jə pɹaɪdfəl, ɡɝl," məleɪn æɾəd wɪð ə fɑn smaɪl.

"Almost, I began to think you prideful, girl," Melaine added with a fond smile.

"ɡɝl noʊ lɔŋɡɝ," æmɪz sɛd.

"Girl no longer," Amys said.

"oʊ, ʃiz stɪl ə ɡɝl," bɛɹ sɛd. "əntɪl wʌn mɔɹ θɪŋ ɪz dʌn."

"Oh, she's still a girl," Bair said. "Until one more thing is done."

eɪvinhə fɛl deɪzd. ðeɪd sɛd ʃi wɑzn lɝnɪŋ kwɪkli ɪnʌf. lɝnɪŋ tə stæn ʌp fəɹ hɝsɛlf! eɪvinhə hæd nɛvɝ əlaʊɾ ʌðɝz tə pʊʃ əɹ ɝaʊnd, bʌt ðiz wɝnt "ʌðɝz" - ðeɪ wɝ waɪz wʌnz, ən ʃi ði əpɹɛntəs. wʌt wʊɾə hæpən ɪf mɪn hædn ɹaɪl hɝ? ʃi wəɾ əv tə θæŋk ðə wʊmən, ɔlðoʊ mɪn dɪdn ɹilaɪz wʌt ʃid dʌn.

Aviendha felt dazed. They'd said she wasn't learning quickly enough. Learning to stand up for herself! Aviendha had never allowed others to push her around, but these weren't "others" - they were Wise Ones, and she the apprentice. What would have happened if Min hadn't riled her? She would have to thank the woman, although Min didn't realize what she'd done.

əntɪl wʌn mɔɹ θɪŋ ɪz dʌn . . . "wʌt mʌst aɪ stɪl du?" eɪvinhə æskt.

Until one more thing is done . . . "What must I still do?" Aviendha asked.

"ɹɪɾiən," bɛɹ sɛd.

"Rhuidean," Bair said.

ʌv kɔɹs. eɪ waɪz wʌn vɪzəɾəd ðət moʊst seɪkɹəd sɪɾi twaɪs ɪn əɹ laɪf. wʌns wən ʃi bɪkeɪm ən əpɹɛntəs, wʌns wən ʃi bɪkeɪm ə fʊl waɪz wʌn.

Of course. A Wise One visited that most sacred city twice in her life. Once when she became an apprentice, once when she became a full Wise One.

"θɪŋz wɪl bi dɪfɹənt, naʊ," məleɪn sɛd. "ɹɪɾiən ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wʌɾ ɪt wʌns wɑz."

"Things will be different, now," Melaine said. "Rhuidean is no longer what it once was."

"ðæɾ ɪz noʊ ɹizən tə əbændən ði oʊld weɪz," bɛɹ ɹɪplaɪd. "ðə sɪɾi meɪ bi oʊpən, bʌt noʊbɑdi wɪl bi fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə wɔk θɹu ðə pɪlɝz. eɪvinhə, jə mʌst - "

"That is no reason to abandon the old ways," Bair replied. "The city may be open, but nobody will be foolish enough to walk through the pillars. Aviendha, you must - "

"bɛɹ," æmɪz kʌɾ ɪn, "ɪf ɪts wɛl wɪð ju, aɪ wəd pɹəfɝ tə tɛl hɝ."

"Bair," Amys cut in, "if it is well with you, I would prefer to tell her."

bɛɹ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd. "jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪts oʊnli ɹaɪt. wi tɝn əɹ bæks ɑn jə naʊ, eɪvinhə. wɪl nɑt si jə əɡɛn əntɪl jə ɹɪtɝn tə əs əz ə sɪstɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fɹəm ə lɔŋ dʒɝni."

Bair hesitated, then nodded. "Yes, of course. It is only right. We turn our backs on you now, Aviendha. We will not see you again until you return to us as a sister returning from a long journey."

"ə sɪstɝ wi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðət wi nu," məleɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. ðə tu tɝn fɹəm hɝ, ðən æmɪz bɪɡæn tə wɔk təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd. eɪvinhə hɝid tə kætʃ ʌp.

"A sister we had forgotten that we knew," Melaine said, smiling. The two turned from her, then Amys began to walk toward the Traveling ground. Aviendha hurried to catch up.

"ju meɪ wɛɹ jəɹ kloʊðɪŋ ðɪs taɪm," æmɪz sɛd, "æz ɪts ðə mɑɹk ə jəɹ steɪʃən. nɔɹməli, aɪ wəd sədʒɛs ðət jə tʃɹævəl tə ðə sɪɾi baɪ fʊt, ivən ðoʊ wi noʊ ʌv tʃɹævlɪŋ naʊ, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðət kʌstəm ɪz bɛs bɛn ɪn ðɪs keɪs. stɪl, jə ʃəd nɑt tʃɹævəl dɝɛkli tə ðə sɪɾi. aɪ sədʒɛs tʃɹævlɪŋ tə koʊld ɹɑks hoʊld ən wɔk fɹəm ðɛɹ. jə mʌst spɛn taɪm ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld læn tə kɑntəmpleɪt jəɹ dʒɝni."

"You may wear your clothing this time," Amys said, "as it is the mark of your station. Normally, I would suggest that you travel to the city by foot, even though we know of Traveling now, but I think that custom is best bent in this case. Still, you should not Travel directly to the city. I suggest Traveling to Cold Rocks Hold and walk from there. You must spend time in the Three-fold Land to contemplate your journey."

eɪvinhə nɑɾəd. "aɪ wɪl niɾ ə wɔɾɝskɪn ən səplaɪz ðɛɹ."

Aviendha nodded. "I will need a waterskin and supplies there."

"ɹɛɾi ən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ jə ət ðə hoʊld," æmɪz sɛd. "wiv bɪn ɪkspɛktɪŋ jə tə lip ðɪs kæzəm sun. jə ʃʊɾə lɛpt ɪt deɪz əɡoʊ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɔl ðə hɪns wi ɡeɪv ju." ʃi aɪɾ eɪvinhə, hu ɡlæns daʊn ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

"Ready and waiting for you at the hold," Amys said. "We've been expecting you to leap this chasm soon. You should have leapt it days ago, considering all the hints we gave you." She eyed Aviendha, who glanced down at the ground.

"ju hæv noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ʃeɪm," æmɪz sɛd. "ðæt bɝɾən ɪz əpɑn ʌs. dɪspaɪt bɛɹz dʒoʊkɪŋ, jə dɪd wɛl. səm wɪmən spɛn mʌnθs ən mʌnθs biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt bɪfɔɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ ðət ðeɪv hæɾ ɪnʌf. wi hæd tə bi hɑɹɾ ɑn ju, tʃaɪld - hɑɹɾɝ ðən aɪv ɛvɝ sin ə ɹɛɾi əpɹɛntəs tʃɹiɾəd.

"You have no reason for shame," Amys said. "That burden is upon us. Despite Bair's joking, you did well. Some women spend months and months being punished before deciding that they have had enough. We had to be hard on you, child - harder than I've ever seen a ready apprentice treated.

ðəɹ ɪz dʒʌst soʊ lɪɾəl taɪm!"

There is just so little time!"

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd," eɪvinhə sɛd. "ænd . . . θæŋk ju."

"I understand," Aviendha said. "And . . . thank you."

æmɪz snɔɹɾɪd. "ju fɔɹst əs tə bi vɛɹi kɹieɪɾɪv. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɪs taɪm jə spɛn ən ðə ʃeɪm jə fɛlt, fəɹ ɪts ðə ʃeɪm ɛni dætsæŋ wɪl noʊ, ʃəd jə kənsaɪn əm tə ðɛɹ feɪt. ən ðeɪ kænɑɾ ɪskeɪp ɪt sɪmpli baɪ dɪmændɪŋ ɹilis."

Amys snorted. "You forced us to be very creative. Remember this time you spent and the shame you felt, for it is the shame any da'tsang will know, should you consign them to their fate. And they cannot escape it simply by demanding release."

"wʌt dʒju də ɪf ən əpɹɛntəs dɪklɛɹz hɝsɛlf ɹɛɾi tə bi ə waɪz wʌn dʊɹɪŋ əɹ fɝs fju mʌnθs ə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ?"

"What do you do if an apprentice declares herself ready to be a Wise One during her first few months of training?"

"stʃɹæp əɹ ə fju taɪmz ən sɛɾ əɹ dɪɡɪŋ hoʊlz, aɪ səspɛkt," æmɪz sɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ʌv ðəɾ ɛvɝ hæpənɪŋ. ðə kloʊsəst wɑz sɪvænə."

"Strap her a few times and set her digging holes, I suspect," Amys said. "I don't know of that ever happening. The closest was Sevanna."

eɪvinhə hæd wʌndɝd waɪ ðə waɪz wʌnz hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wʊmən wɪθaʊt kəmpleɪnt.

Aviendha had wondered why the Wise Ones had accepted the Shaido woman without complaint.

hɝ dɛklɝeɪʃən hæd bɪn ɪnʌf: ən soʊ æmɪz ən ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə æksɛp hɝ.

Her declaration had been enough: and so Amys and the others had been forced to accept her.

æmɪz pʊld əɹ ʃɔl kloʊs. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə bʌndəl fəɹ jə wɪð ðə meɪɾənz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd. wʌns jə ɹitʃ ɹɪɾiən, tʃɹævəl tə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə sɪɾi. jəl faɪn ðə pɪlɝz ʌv ɡlæs.

Amys pulled her shawl close. "There is a bundle for you with the Maidens guarding the Traveling ground. Once you reach Rhuidean, travel to the center of the city. You will find the pillars of glass.

pæs θɹu ðə sɛntɝ ə ðɛm, ðən ɹɪtɝn hɪɹ. spɛnd wɛl jəɹ deɪz ɹʌnɪŋ tə ðə sɪɾi. wi pʊʃt jə hɑɹd soʊ ðət jə wəɾ əv ðɪs taɪm fəɹ kɑntəmpleɪʃən. ɪts laɪkli ðə læs jəl əv fəɹ səm waɪl."

Pass through the center of them, then return here. Spend well your days running to the city. We pushed you hard so that you would have this time for contemplation. It is likely the last you will have for some while."

eɪvinhə nɑɾəd. "ðə bæɾəl kʌmz."

Aviendha nodded. "The battle comes."

"jɛs. ɹɪtɝn kwɪkli wʌns jə pæs θɹu ðə pɪlɝz. wɪl nid tə dɪskʌs haʊ tə bɛs hændəl ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn. hiz . . . tʃeɪnʒd sɪns læs naɪt."

"Yes. Return quickly once you pass through the pillars. We will need to discuss how to best handle the Car'a'carn. He has . . . changed since last night."

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd," eɪvinhə sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ.

"I understand," Aviendha said, taking a deep breath.

"ɡoʊ," æmɪz sɛd, "æn ɹɪtɝn." ʃi pʊɾ ɛmfəsəs ɑn ðə faɪnəl wɝd. səm wɪmən dɪd nɑt sɝvaɪv ɹɪɾiən.

"Go," Amys said, "and return." She put emphasis on the final word. Some women did not survive Rhuidean.

eɪvinhə mɛɾ æmɪz' aɪz, ən nɑɾəd. æmɪz hæd bɪn ə sɛkən mʌðɝ tə hɝ ɪn mɛni weɪz. ʃi wɑz ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd baɪ ə ɹɛɹ smaɪl. ðən æmɪz tɝn əɹ bæk tə eɪvinhə, dʒʌst əz ði ʌðɝ tu hæd.

Aviendha met Amys' eyes, and nodded. Amys had been a second mother to her in many ways. She was rewarded by a rare smile. Then Amys turned her back to Aviendha, just as the other two had.

eɪvinhə tʊk ənʌðɝ dip bɹɛθ, ɡlænsɪŋ bæk əkɹɔs ðə tʃɹæmpəld ɡɹæs bɪfɔɹ ðə mænɝ haʊs tə wɛɹ ɹænd spoʊk wɪð ðə kɔɹɾɝmæstɝz, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən stɝn, ði ɑɹm mɪsɪŋ ə hæn hɛl foʊldəd bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, ði ʌðɝ ɑɹm dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ænəmeɪɾɪdli. ʃi smaɪld ət hɪm, ðoʊ hi wɑzn lʊkɪŋ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən.

Aviendha took another deep breath, glancing back across the trampled grass before the manor house to where Rand spoke with the quartermasters, his expression stern, the arm missing a hand held folded behind his back, the other arm gesturing animatedly. She smiled at him, though he wasn't looking in her direction.

əl bi bæk fəɹ ju, ʃi θɔt.

I will be back for you, she thought.

ðən ʃi tʃɹɑɾəd tə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd, kəlɛktəd ðə pæk ən woʊv ə ɡeɪtweɪ ðət wəd dəpɑzɪɾ əɹ ə seɪf dɪstəns fɹəm koʊld ɹɑks hoʊld, bɪsaɪɾ ə ɹɑk fɔɹmeɪʃən noʊn əz ðə meɪɾənz spɪɹ, fɹəm wɪtʃ ʃi kəd ɹʌn tə ðə hoʊld ən pɹipɛɹ hɝsɛlf. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən tə ðə fəmɪljɝ, dʒɹaɪ ɛɹ ə ðə weɪst.

Then she trotted to the Traveling ground, collected the pack and wove a gateway that would deposit her a safe distance from Cold Rocks Hold, beside a rock formation known as the Maiden's Spear, from which she could run to the hold and prepare herself. The gateway opened to the familiar, dry air of the Waste.

ʃi dʌk θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ɪɡzʌltɪŋ - faɪnəli - ɪn wʌt hæd dʒʌs hæpənd.

She ducked through the gateway, exulting - finally - in what had just happened.

hɝ ɑnɝ hæd ɹɪtɝnd.

Her honor had returned.

"aɪ keɪm aʊt θɹu ə smɔl wɔɾɝɡeɪt, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃimɹɪn sɛd, boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə tɛnt. "ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɪt wɑzn soʊ dɪfəkəlt, wʌns aɪ lɛf ðə taʊɝ ən ɡɑɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. aɪ dɪdn dɛɹ liv baɪ wʌn ə ðə bɹɪdʒəz. aɪ kʊdn lɛt ði æmɪɝlɪn noʊ wʌɾ aɪ wɑz duɪŋ."

"I came out through a small watergate, Aes Sedai," Shemerin said, bowing her head before the others in the tent. "In truth, it wasn't so difficult, once I left the Tower and got into the city. I didn't dare leave by one of the bridges. I couldn't let the Amyrlin know what I was doing."

ɹoʊmændə wɑtʃt, ɑɹmz foʊldəd. hɝ tɛnt wɑz lɪt baɪ tu bɹæs læmps, fleɪmz dænsɪŋ ət ðə tɪps.

Romanda watched, arms folded. Her tent was lit by two brass lamps, flames dancing at the tips.

sɪks wɪmən lɪsən tə ðə ɹʌnəweɪz stɔɹi. ləleɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, fəɹ ɔl ðət ɹoʊmændə hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kip əɹ fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ əbaʊt ðə miɾɪŋ. ɹoʊmændə hæd hoʊp ðət ðə slɛndɝ blu wəd bi tu bɪzi bæskɪŋ ɪn əɹ stæɾəs ɪn kæmp tə bɑðɝ wɪð sətʃ ə simɪŋli tʃɹɪviəl ɪvɛnt.

Six women listened to the runaway's story. Lelaine was there, for all that Romanda had tried to keep her from hearing about the meeting. Romanda had hoped that the slender Blue would be too busy basking in her status in camp to bother with such a seemingly trivial event.

bɪsaɪɾ əɹ wɑz sɪuən. ðə fɔɹmɝ æmɪɝlɪn hæd lætʃt hɝsɛlf ɑn tə ləleɪn wɪð ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ʌv ə bɑɹnəkəl. ɹoʊmændə wɑz wɛl ɪnʌf plizd wɪð ðə nufaʊn əbɪləɾi tə hil ə stɪlɪŋ - ʃi wɑz jɛloʊ æftɝ ɔl - bʌɾ ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɪʃt ɪt hædn hæpən tə sɪuən. əz ɪf ləleɪn wɝn bæɾ ɪnʌf tə dil wɪð. ɹoʊmændə hæd nɑt fɝɡɑɾən sɪuənz kɹæfti neɪtʃɝ, ivən ɪf soʊ mɛni ʌðɝz ɪn kæmp sim tə hæv dʌn soʊ. lɛsɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ dɪd nɑt min dɪkɹis kəpæsəɾi fəɹ skimɪŋ.

Beside her was Siuan. The former Amyrlin had latched herself on to Lelaine with the strength of a barnacle. Romanda was well enough pleased with the newfound ability to Heal a stilling - she was Yellow after all - but a part of her wished it hadn't happened to Siuan. As if Lelaine weren't bad enough to deal with. Romanda had not forgotten Siuan's crafty nature, even if so many others in camp seemed to have done so. Lesser strength in the Power did not mean decreased capacity for scheming.

ʃɛɹiəm wɑz ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə ɹɛd-hɛɹd kipɝ sæt bɪsaɪd ləleɪn. ʃɛɹiəm hæd bɪn wɪθdʒɹɔn leɪtli, ən bɛɹli meɪnteɪn ðə dɪɡnəɾi ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. fulɪʃ wʊmən. ʃi niɾəd tə bi ɹimuv fɹəm əɹ pleɪs; ɛvɹiwʌn kəd si ðæt. ɪf ɛɡwin ɛvɝ ɹɪtɝnd - ən ɹoʊmændə pɹeɪd ðət ʃi dɪd, ɪf oʊnli kəz ɪt wəɾ əpsɛt ləleɪnz plænz - ðən ðəɹ wəd bi ən ɑpɝtunəɾi. ə nu kipɝ.

Sheriam was there, of course. The red-haired Keeper sat beside Lelaine. Sheriam had been withdrawn lately, and barely maintained the dignity of an Aes Sedai. Foolish woman. She needed to be removed from her place; everyone could see that. If Egwene ever returned - and Romanda prayed that she did, if only because it would upset Lelaine's plans - then there would be an opportunity. A new Keeper.

ði ʌðɝ pɝsən ɪn ðə tɛnt wɑz mæɡlə. ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn hæɾ ɑɹɡjud - wɪð kəntʃɹoʊl, ʌv kɔɹs - oʊvɝ u wəd bi fɝs tə ɪntɛɹəɡeɪt ʃimɹɪn. ðeɪd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət ði oʊnli fɛɹ weɪ wɑz tə də ɪt təɡɛðɝ. kəz ʃimɹɪn wɑz jɛloʊ, ɹoʊmændə hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə kɔl ðə miɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ oʊn tɛnt. ɪt hæd bɪn ə ʃɑk wən ləleɪn hæd ʃoʊn ʌp wɪð nɑt dʒʌst sɪuən bʌt ʃɛɹiəm ɪn toʊ. bʌt ðeɪd nɛvɝ sɛd haʊ mɛni ətɛndəns ðeɪ kəd bɹɪŋ. ən soʊ ɹoʊmændə wɑz lɛft wɪð oʊnli mæɡlə.

The other person in the tent was Magla. Romanda and Lelaine had argued - with control, of course - over who would be first to interrogate Shemerin. They'd decided that the only fair way was to do it together. Because Shemerin was Yellow, Romanda had been able to call the meeting in her own tent. It had been a shock when Lelaine had shown up with not just Siuan but Sheriam in tow. But they'd never said how many attendants they could bring. And so Romanda was left with only Magla.

ðə θɪk-ʃoʊldɝd wʊmən sæt bɪsaɪd ɹoʊmændə, lɪsnɪŋ kwaɪətli tə ðə kənfɛʃən. ʃəd ɹoʊmændə hæv sɛn fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls? ɪt wʊɾə lʊk vɛɹi ɑbviəs, dɪleɪɪŋ ðə miɾɪŋ fəɹ ðæt.

The thick-shouldered woman sat beside Romanda, listening quietly to the confession. Should Romanda have sent for someone else? It would have looked very obvious, delaying the meeting for that.

ɪt wɑzn ɹɪli ən ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃən, haʊɛvɝ. ʃimɹɪn spoʊk fɹili, wɪθaʊt ɹɪzɪstɪŋ kwɛstʃənz. ʃi sæɾ ɑn ə smɔl stul bɪfɔɹ ðɛm. ʃid ɹəfjuzd ə kʊʃən fəɹ ɪt. ɹoʊmændə hæd ɹɛɹli sin ə wʊmən əz dɪtɝmən tə pʌnɪʃ hɝsɛlf əz ðɪs pʊɹ tʃaɪld.

It wasn't really an interrogation, however. Shemerin spoke freely, without resisting questions. She sat on a small stool before them. She'd refused a cushion for it. Romanda had rarely seen a woman as determined to punish herself as this poor child.

nɑɾ ə tʃaɪld, ɹoʊmændə θɔt. ə fʊl ɛɛs sədaɪ, wʌtɛvɝ ʃi sɛz. bɝn ju, ɪleɪɾə, fəɹ tɝnɪŋ wʌn ʌv əs ɪndə ðɪs!

Not a child, Romanda thought. A full Aes Sedai, whatever she says. Burn you, Elaida, for turning one of us into this!

ʃimɹɪn hæd bɪn jɛloʊ. bɝn ɪt, ʃi wɑz jɛloʊ. ʃid bɪn tɔkɪŋ tə ðɛm fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ən aʊɝ naʊ, ænsɝɪŋ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ðə stæɾəs ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. sɪuən hæd bɪn ðə fɝs tə æsk haʊ ðə wʊmən hæd kʌm tə ɪskeɪp.

Shemerin had been Yellow. Burn it, she was Yellow. She'd been talking to them for the better part of an hour now, answering questions about the status of the White Tower. Siuan had been the first to ask how the woman had come to escape.

"pliz fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ sikɪŋ wɝk ɪn ðə kæmp wɪθaʊt kʌmɪŋ tə ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃimɹɪn sɛd, hɛd baʊd. "bʌɾ aɪ hæv flɛd ðə taʊɝ əɡɛns ðə lɔ. əz ən æksɛptɪd livɪŋ wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən, aɪm ə ɹʌnəweɪ. aɪ nu aɪ wəd bi pʌnɪʃt ɪf dɪskʌvɝd.

"Please forgive me for seeking work in the camp without coming to you, Aes Sedai," Shemerin said, head bowed. "But I have fled the Tower against the law. As an Accepted leaving without permission, I am a runaway. I knew I would be punished if discovered.

"aɪ hæv steɪɾ ɪn ðɪs ɛɹiə kəz ɪts soʊ fəmɪljɝ, ən aɪ kænɑt lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ. wən jəɹ ɑɹmi keɪm, aɪ sɔ ə tʃæns fəɹ wɝk, ən aɪ tʊk ɪt. bʌt pliz, də nɑt fɔɹs mi tə ɡoʊ bæk. əl nɑt bi ə deɪnʒɝ. əl sik ə laɪf əz ə nɔɹməl wʊmən, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə juz maɪ əbɪləɾiz."

"I have stayed in this area because it is so familiar, and I cannot let it go. When your army came, I saw a chance for work, and I took it. But please, do not force me to go back. I will not be a danger. I will seek a life as a normal woman, careful not to use my abilities."

"ju ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɹoʊmændə sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ði ɛdʒ aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs. ðɪs wʊmənz æɾətud lɛn mʌtʃ kɹiɾəns tə ðə θɪŋz ɛɡwin sɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪleɪɾəz paʊɝ-hʌŋɡɹi ɹeɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ. "noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪleɪɾə sɛz."

"You are Aes Sedai," Romanda said, trying to keep the edge out of her voice. This woman's attitude lent much credence to the things Egwene said about Elaida's power-hungry reign in the Tower. "No matter what Elaida says."

"aɪ. . . ." ʃimɹɪn dʒʌst ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. laɪt! ʃi nɛvɝ hæd bɪn ðə moʊs pɔɪzd ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ʃɑkɪŋ tə si hɝ fɔlən soʊ fɑɹ.

"I. . . ." Shemerin just shook her head. Light! She never had been the most poised of Aes Sedai, but it was shocking to see her fallen so far.

"tɛl mi əbaʊt ðɪs wɔɾɝɡeɪt," sɪuən sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. "wɛɹ kəd wi faɪn ɪt?"

"Tell me about this watergate," Siuan said, leaning forward in her chair. "Where could we find it?"

"ɑn ðə saʊθwɛstɝn saɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃimɹɪn sɛd. "əbaʊt faɪv mɪnəts' wɔk istwɝd fɹəm wɛɹ ði eɪntʃən stætʃuz ʌv ɛləiən əlændɝɪn ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝz stænd." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, sʌɾənli simɪŋ æŋkʃəs. "bʌɾ ɪts ə smɔl ɡeɪt. jə kʊdn teɪk ən ɑɹmi θɹu ɪt. aɪ oʊnli noʊ ʌv ɪt kəz aɪ hæd ðə duɾi ʌv kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə bɛɡɝz u lɪv ðɛɹ."

"On the southwestern side of the city, Aes Sedai," Shemerin said. "About five minutes' walk eastward from where the ancient statues of Eleyan al'Landerin and her Warders stand." She hesitated, suddenly seeming anxious. "But it is a small gate. You couldn't take an army through it. I only know of it because I had the duty of caring for the beggars who live there."

"aɪ wɑn ə mæp ɛniweɪ," sɪuən sɛd, ðən ʃi ɡlænst ət ləleɪn. "æt list, aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəɾ əv wʌn."

"I want a map anyway," Siuan said, then she glanced at Lelaine. "At least, I think we should have one."

"ɪɾ ɪz ə waɪz aɪdiə," ləleɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə nɔsiɾɪŋli mæɡnænəməs toʊn.

"It is a wise idea," Lelaine said in a nauseatingly magnanimous tone.

"aɪ də wɑnə noʊ mɔɹ ə jəɹ . . . sɪtʃueɪʃən," mæɡlə sɛd. "haʊ ɪz ɪɾ ɪleɪɾə kəd θɪŋk ðət dɪmoʊɾɪŋ ə sɪstɝ wɑz waɪz? ɛɡwin dɪd spik ə ðɪs ɪvɛnt, ən aɪ dɪd faɪn ɪɾ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ðɛn, tu.

"I do want to know more of your . . . situation," Magla said. "How is it Elaida could think that demoting a sister was wise? Egwene did speak of this event, and I did find it incredible then, too.

wʌt wɑz ɪleɪɾəz θɔt?"

What was Elaida's thought?"

"aɪ . . . kænɑt spik fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪnz θɔt," ʃimɹɪn sɛd. ʃi kɹɪnʒd əz ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə ɹum ɡeɪv əɹ ə sɛɾ ə nɑt-soʊ-sʌɾəl ɡlɛɹz ət kɔlɪŋ ɪleɪɾə ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɹoʊmændə dɪdn dʒɔɪn ɪn.

"I . . . cannot speak for the Amyrlin's thought," Shemerin said. She cringed as the women in the room gave her a set of not-so-subtle glares at calling Elaida the Amyrlin. Romanda didn't join in.

sʌmθɪŋ smɔl wɑz kɹipɪŋ bɪniθ ðə kænvəs flɔɹ ə ðə tɛnt, muvɪŋ fɹəm wʌn kɔɹnɝ təwɔɹd ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum. laɪt! wɑz ðəɾ ə maʊs? noʊ, ɪt wɑz tu smɔl. pɝhæps ə kɹɪkət. ʃi ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli.

Something small was creeping beneath the canvas floor of the tent, moving from one corner toward the center of the room. Light! Was that a mouse? No, it was too small. Perhaps a cricket. She shifted uncomfortably.

"bʌt ʃʊɹli jə dɪd də sʌmθɪŋ tə ɝn əɹ aɪɹ," mæɡlə sɛd. "sʌmθɪŋ wɝði ʌv sətʃ tʃɹitmənt?"

"But surely you did do something to earn her ire," Magla said. "Something worthy of such treatment?"

"aɪ. . . ." ʃimɹɪn sɛd. ʃi kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ ət sɪuən fəɹ səm ɹizən.

"I. . . ." Shemerin said. She kept glancing at Siuan for some reason.

ful wʊmən. ɹoʊmændə ɔlmoʊs θɔɾ ɪleɪɾə hæd meɪd ðə ɹaɪt muv. ʃimɹɪn ʃəd nɛvɝ əv bɪn ɡɪvən ðə ʃɔl. ʌv kɔɹs, dɪmoʊɾɪŋ əɹ tə æksɛptɪd wɑz noʊ weɪ tə hændəl ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən iðɝ. ði æmɪɝlɪn kʊdn bi ɡɪvən ðət mʌtʃ paʊɝ.

Fool woman. Romanda almost thought Elaida had made the right move. Shemerin should never have been given the shawl. Of course, demoting her to Accepted was no way to handle the situation either. The Amyrlin couldn't be given that much power.

jɛs, ðət wɑz dɛfənətli sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə kænvəs, dətɝmənədli pʊʃɪŋ ɪts weɪ tə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə tɛnt, ə taɪni lʌmp muvɪŋ ɪn dʒɝks ən stɑɹts.

Yes, that was definitely something under the canvas, determinedly pushing its way to the center of the tent, a tiny lump moving in jerks and starts.

"aɪ wɑz wik bɪfɔɹ hɝ," ʃimɹɪn faɪnəli sɛd. "wi wɝ spikɪŋ ʌv . . . ɪvɛns ɪn ðə wɝld. aɪ kəd nɑt stʌmək ðɛm. aɪ dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ pɔɪz bɪfɪɾɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"I was weak before her," Shemerin finally said. "We were speaking of . . . events in the world. I could not stomach them. I did not show poise befitting an Aes Sedai."

"ðæts ɪt?" ləleɪn æskt. "ju dɪdn plɑɾ əɡɛns hɝ? jə dɪdn kɑntʃɹədɪk hɝ?"

"That's it?" Lelaine asked. "You didn't plot against her? You didn't contradict her?"

ʃimɹɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ wɑz lɔɪəl."

Shemerin shook her head. "I was loyal."

"aɪ faɪn ðət hɑɹd tə bɪliv," ləleɪn sɛd.

"I find that hard to believe," Lelaine said.

"aɪ bɪliv hɝ," sɪuən sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ʃimɹɪn ʃoʊd wɛl ɪnʌf ʃi wɑz ɪn ɪleɪɾəz pɑkəɾ ɑn sɛvɹəl əkeɪʒənz."

"I believe her," Siuan said dryly. "Shemerin showed well enough she was in Elaida's pocket on several occasions."

"ðɪs də bi ə deɪnʒɝəs pɹɛsɪɾənt," mæɡlə noʊɾəd. "bɝn maɪ soʊl, bʌɾ ɪt du."

"This do be a dangerous precedent," Magla noted. "Burn my soul, but it do."

"jɛs," ɹoʊmændə əɡɹid, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kænvəs-kʌvɝd wʌtɛvɝ-ɪt-wɑz ɪntʃ əlɔŋ bɪfɔɹ hɝ. "aɪ səspɛkt ʃi juz pʊɹ ʃimɹɪn əz ən ɪɡzæmpəl, ækləmeɪɾɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə ðə kɑnsɛpt ə dɪmoʊʃən. ðət wɪl lɛɾ əɹ juz ɪɾ ɑn ðoʊz u ɑɹ æktʃəli  hɝ ɛnəmiz."

"Yes," Romanda agreed, watching the canvas-covered whatever-it-was inch along before her. "I suspect she used poor Shemerin as an example, acclimating the White Tower to the concept of demotion. That will let her use it on those who are actually her enemies."

ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən hɪɾ ə lʌl. ðə sɪɾɝz u səpɔɹɾəd ɛɡwin wəd laɪkli hɛd ðə lɪst ə ðoʊz tə bi dɪmoʊɾɪd, ɪf ɪleɪɾə ɹɪteɪn əɹ paʊɝ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɛkənsaɪld.

The conversation hit a lull. The Sitters who supported Egwene would likely head the list of those to be demoted, if Elaida retained her power and the Aes Sedai reconciled.

"ɪz ðəɾ ə maʊs?" sɪuən æskt, lʊkɪŋ daʊn.

"Is that a mouse?" Siuan asked, looking down.

"ɪts tu smɔl," ɹoʊmændə sɛd. "æn ɪts nɑɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt."

"It's too small," Romanda said. "And it's not important."

"smɔl?" ləleɪn sɛd, linɪŋ daʊn.

"Small?" Lelaine said, leaning down.

ɹoʊmændə fɹaʊnd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə spɑɾ əɡɛn. ɪt dɪd sim tə hæv ɡɹoʊn lɑɹdʒɝ. ɪn fækt -  ðə bʌmp dʒɝk sʌɾənli, pʊʃɪŋ ʌpwɝd. ðə kænvəs flɔɹ splɪt, ən ə θɪk-bɑɾid kɑkɹoʊtʃ  - əz waɪɾ əz ə fɪɡ - skɹæmbəl θɹu. ɹoʊmændə pʊl bæk ɪn ɹɪvʌlʃən.

Romanda frowned, glancing at the spot again. It did seem to have grown larger. In fact -  The bump jerked suddenly, pushing upward. The canvas floor split, and a thick-bodied cockroach  - as wide as a fig - scrambled through. Romanda pulled back in revulsion.

ðə ɹoʊtʃ skɪɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə kænvəs, æntɛni twɪtʃɪŋ. sɪuən tʊk ɔf əɹ ʃu tə swɑɾ ɪt. bʌt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə tɛn bʌbəld ʌp nɪɹ ðə ɹɪp, ən ə sɛkən kɑkɹoʊtʃ klaɪm θɹu. ðən ə θɝd.

The roach skittered across the canvas, antennae twitching. Siuan took off her shoe to swat it. But the bottom of the tent bubbled up near the rip, and a second cockroach climbed through. Then a third.

ən ðən ə weɪv ə ðɛm, pɔɹɪŋ θɹu ðə splɪt laɪk tu-hɑt ti spɹeɪd fɹəm ə maʊθ. ə blæk ən bɹaʊn kɑɹpəɾ ə skɹæmbəlɪŋ, skɹætʃɪŋ, skɝiɪŋ kɹitʃɝz, pʊʃɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðɛɹ hɝi tə ɡɛɾ aʊt.

And then a wave of them, pouring through the split like too-hot tea sprayed from a mouth. A black and brown carpet of scrambling, scratching, scurrying creatures, pushing over one another in their hurry to get out.

ðə wɪmən skɹitʃt ɪn ɹɪvʌlʃən, θɹoʊɪŋ bæk stulz ən tʃɛɹz əz ðeɪ stʊd. wɔɹɾɝz wɝ ɪn ðə ɹum ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ; bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd ɹɔɹɪk bɑndəd tə mæɡlə, ən ðət kɑpɝi-skɪn stoʊn ʌv ə mæn wɑz bɛɹɪn ʃeɪɝən, bɑndəd tə ləleɪn. ðeɪ hæd sɔɹdz dʒɹɔn ət ðə skɹimz, bʌt ðə kɑkɹoʊtʃɪz sim tə stʌmp ðɛm. ðeɪ stʊd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə stʃɹim ə fɪlθi ɪnsɛks.

The women screeched in revulsion, throwing back stools and chairs as they stood. Warders were in the room a moment later; broad-shouldered Rorik bonded to Magla, and that coppery-skinned stone of a man was Burin Shaeren, bonded to Lelaine. They had swords drawn at the screams, but the cockroaches seemed to stump them. They stood, staring at the stream of filthy insects.

ʃɛɹiəm hɑpt ʌp ɑn əɹ tʃɛɹ. sɪuən tʃænəld ən bɪɡæn tə skwɑʃ ðə kɹitʃɝz kloʊsəs tə hɝ.

Sheriam hopped up on her chair. Siuan channeled and began to squash the creatures closest to her.

ɹoʊmændə heɪɾəd tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ fəɹ dɛθ, ivən ɑn sətʃ vaɪl kɹitʃɝz, bʌt ʃi tu faʊn hɝsɛlf tʃænəlɪŋ ɛɹ ən smæʃɪŋ ði ɪnsɛks ɪn swɑθs, bʌt ðə kɹitʃɝz wɝ pɔɹɪŋ ɪn tu kwɪkli.

Romanda hated to use the One Power for death, even on such vile creatures, but she too found herself channeling Air and smashing the insects in swaths, but the creatures were pouring in too quickly.

sun ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz swɔɹmɪŋ wɪð ðɛm, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ fɔɹs tə skɹæmbəl aʊɾ ə ðə tɛn ən ɪndə ðə kwaɪət dɑɹknəs ə ðə kæmp. ɹɔɹɪk pʊl ðə flæps ʃʌt, ðoʊ ðət wʊdn stɑp ði ɪnsɛks fɹəm skwizɪŋ aʊt.

Soon the ground was swarming with them, and the Aes Sedai were forced to scramble out of the tent and into the quiet darkness of the camp. Rorik pulled the flaps shut, though that wouldn't stop the insects from squeezing out.

aʊtsaɪd, ɹoʊmændə kʊdn stɑp hɝsɛlf fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɝ hɛɹ, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs, tə meɪk sɝɾən nʌn ə ðə kɹitʃɝz hæd ɡɑɾən ɪndə ɪt. ʃi ʃɪvɝɾ əz ʃi ɪmædʒən ðə kɹitʃɝz skɹæmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ bɑɾi.

Outside, Romanda couldn't stop herself from running her fingers through her hair, just in case, to make certain none of the creatures had gotten into it. She shivered as she imagined the creatures scrambling over her body.

"ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ðə tɛn ðəɾ ɪz dɪɹ tə ju?" ləleɪn æskt, lʊkɪŋ bæk ət ðə tɛnt. θɹu ðə læmplaɪt, ʃi kəd si ðə ʃæɾoʊi ɪnsɛks skɝiɪŋ ʌp ðə wɔlz.

"Is there anything in the tent that is dear to you?" Lelaine asked, looking back at the tent. Through the lamplight, she could see the shadowy insects scurrying up the walls.

ɹoʊmændə spɛɹɾ ə θɔt fəɹ əɹ dʒɝnəl, bʌt nu ðət ʃid nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə tʌtʃ ðoʊz peɪdʒəz æftɝ əɹ tɛn hæd bɪn ɪnfɛstəd ðɪs weɪ. "nʌθɪŋ ðəɾ aɪd kɛɹ tə kip naʊ," ʃi sɛd, wivɪŋ faɪɝ.

Romanda spared a thought for her journal, but knew that she'd never be able to touch those pages after her tent had been infested this way. "Nothing that I'd care to keep now," she said, weaving Fire.

"ænd nʌθɪŋ aɪ kæn ɹipleɪs."

"And nothing I can't replace."

ði ʌðɝz dʒɔɪn hɝ, ən ðə tɛn bɝst ɪndə fleɪmz, ɹɔɹɪk dʒʌmpɪŋ bæk əz ðeɪ tʃænəld.

The others joined her, and the tent burst into flames, Rorik jumping back as they channeled.

ɹoʊmændə θɔt ʃi hɝd ði ɪnsɛks pɑpɪŋ ən sɪzəlɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ muv bæk fɹəm ðə sʌɾən hit. ɪn moʊməns, ði ɪntaɪɝ tɛnt wɑz ən ɪnfɝnoʊ. wɪmən ɹʌʃt aʊɾ ə nɪɹbaɪ tɛns tə lʊk.

Romanda thought she heard the insects popping and sizzling inside. The Aes Sedai moved back from the sudden heat. In moments, the entire tent was an inferno. Women rushed out of nearby tents to look.

"aɪ də noʊ θɪŋk ðət wɑz nætʃɹəl," mæɡlə sɛd sɔfli. "ðoʊz dɪd bi fɔɹ-spaɪn ɹoʊtʃɪz. seɪlɝz də si ðɛm ɑn ʃɪps ðət vɪzət ʃɑɹə."

"I do no think that was natural," Magla said softly. "Those did be four-spine roaches. Sailors do see them on ships that visit Shara."

"wɛl, ɪɾ ɪzən ðə wɝst wiv sin fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌn," sɪuən sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "ænd wɪl si wɝs jɛt, mɑɹk maɪ wɝdz." ʃi aɪd ʃimɹɪn. "kʌm, aɪ wɑn ðət mæp fɹəm ju."

"Well, it isn't the worst we've seen from the Dark One," Siuan said, folding her arms. "And we'll see worse yet, mark my words." She eyed Shemerin. "Come, I want that map from you."

ðeɪ lɛft wɪð ɹɔɹɪk ən ði ʌðɝz, hu wəɾ əlɝt ðə kæmp ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn hæd tʌtʃt ɪt ðɪs naɪt. ɹoʊmændə stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tɛn bɝn. sun ɪt wɑz oʊnli smoʊldɝɪŋ koʊlz.

They left with Rorik and the others, who would alert the camp that the Dark One had touched it this night. Romanda stood watching the tent burn. Soon it was only smoldering coals.

laɪt, ʃi θɔt. ɛɡwin ɪz ɹaɪt. ɪts kʌmɪŋ. fæst. ən ðə ɡɝl wɑz ɪmpɹɪzənd naʊ; ʃid mɛt wɪð ðə hɔl ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, ɪnfɔɹmɪŋ əm ə hɝ dɪzæstʃɹəs dɪnɝ wɪð ɪleɪɾə ən ði æftɝmæθ ʌv ɪnsʌltɪŋ ðə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn. ən jɛɾ ɛɡwin stɪl ɹəfjuzd ɹɛskju.

Light, she thought. Egwene is right. It is coming. Fast. And the girl was imprisoned now; she'd met with the Hall the night before in the World of Dreams, informing them of her disastrous dinner with Elaida and the aftermath of insulting the false Amyrlin. And yet Egwene still refused rescue.

tɔɹtʃɪz wɝ lɪɾ ən wɔɹɾɝz ɹaʊzd əz ə pɹikɔʃən əɡɛns mɔɹ ivəl. ʃi smɛl smoʊk. ðət wɑz ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ʌv ɔl ʃi hæɾ oʊn ɪn ðə wɝld.

Torches were lit and Warders roused as a precaution against more evil. She smelled smoke. That was the remains of all she had owned in the world.

ðə taʊɝ niɾəd tə bi hoʊl. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt tʊk. wəd ʃi bi wɪlɪŋ tə baʊ bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪɾə tə meɪk ðət hæpən? wəd ʃi pʊɾ ɑn ən æksɛptɪd dʒɹɛs əɡɛn ɪf ɪt wəd bɹɪŋ junəɾi fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl?

The Tower needed to be whole. Whatever it took. Would she be willing to bow before Elaida to make that happen? Would she put on an Accepted dress again if it would bring unity for the Last Battle?

ʃi kʊdn dɪsaɪd. ən ðət dɪstɝbd əɹ nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ðoʊz skʌɾəlɪŋ ɹoʊtʃɪz hæd.

She couldn't decide. And that disturbed her nearly as much as those scuttling roaches had.

tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən

CHAPTER 27

ðə tɪpsi ɡɛldɪŋ mæt dɪdn ɪskeɪp ðə kæmp wɪθaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. blʌɾi wɪmən.

The Tipsy Gelding Mat didn't escape the camp without the Aes Sedai, of course. Bloody women.

hi ɹoʊd daʊn ði eɪntʃən stoʊn ɹoʊdweɪ, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɑloʊd baɪ ðə bænd. hi wɑz, haʊɛvɝ, əkʌmpənid baɪ ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu wɔɹɾɝz, faɪv soʊlʒɝz, tælmɑnz, ə pæk ænəməl ən tɑm.

He rode down the ancient stone roadway, no longer followed by the Band. He was, however, accompanied by the three Aes Sedai, two Warders, five soldiers, Talmanes, a pack animal and Thom.

ət list ɑlʌdʒɹə, æməðɛɹə ən ɛdʒiənɪn hædn ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn kʌmɪŋ. ðɪs ɡɹup wɑz tu bɪɡ əz ɪt wɑz.

At least Aludra, Amathera and Egeanin hadn't insisted on coming. This group was too big as it was.

ðə θɹi-niɾəl paɪnz ɡɑɹɾəd ðə ɹoʊd, smɛlɪŋ ə paɪn sæp, ən ði ɛɹ wɑz məlɑɾɪk wɪð maʊntən fɪntʃɪz' kɔlz. ɪt wɑz stɪl sɛvɹəl aʊɝz əntɪl sʌndaʊn; hid hɔltəd ðə bænd nɪɹ nun. hi ɹoʊd slaɪtli əhɛɾ ə ðə klʌstɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz. æftɝ hid ɹəfjuz dʒoʊlin hɔɹsəz ən fʌnz, ðeɪ hædn bɪn əbaʊt tə lɛɾ ɪm wɪn ənʌðɝ pɔɪnt. nɑt wən ðeɪ kəd fɔɹs ɪm tə teɪk əm daʊn tə ðə vɪlədʒ, wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd spɛn ət list wʌn naɪɾ ɪn ən ɪn wɪð sɑf bɛdz ən wɔɹm bæθs.

The three-needle pines guarded the road, smelling of pine sap, and the air was melodic with mountain finches' calls. It was still several hours until sundown; he'd halted the Band near noon. He rode slightly ahead of the clustered Aes Sedai and Warders. After he'd refused Joline horses and funds, they hadn't been about to let him win another point. Not when they could force him to take them down to the village, where they could spend at least one night in an inn with soft beds and warm baths.

hi dɪdn ɑɹɡju tu laʊdli. hi heɪɾəd tə hæv mɔɹ tʌŋz wæɡɪŋ əbaʊt ðə bænd, ən wɪmən dɪd ɡɑsəp, ivən ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl tʃæns ə ðə bæn pæsɪŋ wɪθaʊt kɑzɪŋ ə stɝ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ ɛniweɪ. ɪf ɛni sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊlz meɪɾ ɪt θɹu ðiz twɪstɪŋ maʊntən pæðz. . . . wɛl, mæt wəd dʒʌst əv tə kip ðə bæn ɑn ə stɛɾi peɪs nɔɹθwɝɾ ən ðət wɑz ðæt. noʊ jus kɹaɪɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt.

He didn't argue too loudly. He hated to have more tongues wagging about the Band, and women did gossip, even Aes Sedai. But there was little chance of the Band passing without causing a stir in the village anyway. If any Seanchan patrols made it through these twisting mountain paths. . . . Well, Mat would just have to keep the Band on a steady pace northward and that was that. No use crying about it.

bɪsaɪdz, hi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fil ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn, ɹaɪɾɪŋ pɪps daʊn ðət ɹoʊd, spɹɪŋ bɹiz kɹɪsp ɪn ði ɛɹ. hid teɪkən tə wɛɹɪŋ wʌn ə hɪz oʊldɝ koʊts, ɹɛd wɪð bɹaʊn tʃɹɪm, ənbʌɾənd tə ʃoʊ hɪz oʊl tæn ʃɝt bɪniθ.

Besides, he was beginning to feel right again, riding Pips down that road, spring breeze crisp in the air. He'd taken to wearing one of his older coats, red with brown trim, unbuttoned to show his old tan shirt beneath.

ðɪs wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wɑz əbaʊt. tʃɹævlɪŋ tə nu vɪlədʒəz, θɹoʊɪŋ daɪs ɪn ði ɪnz, pɪntʃɪŋ ə fju bɑɹmeɪdz. hi wəd nɑt θɪŋk ə tuɑn. fleɪmɪŋ sintʃæn. ʃid bi ɔl ɹaɪt, wʊdnt ʃi?

This was what it was about. Traveling to new villages, throwing dice in the inns, pinching a few barmaids. He would not think of Tuon. Flaming Seanchan. She'd be all right, wouldn't she?

noʊ. hɪz hænz ɔlmoʊst ɪtʃt tə bi ət ðə dɪsɪŋ. ɪt hæd bɪn fɑɹ tu lɔŋ sɪns hid sæt daʊn ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ sʌmwɛɹ ən θɹoʊn wɪð ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi sɔɹt. ðeɪd bi ə lɪɾəl dɝɾiɝ ə feɪs ən kɔɹsɝ ə læŋɡwədʒ, bʌɾ əz ɡʊɾ ə hɑɹɾ əz ɛni mæn. bɛɾɝ ðən moʊs lɔɹdz.

No. His hands almost itched to be at the dicing. It had been far too long since he'd sat down in a corner somewhere and thrown with the ordinary sort. They'd be a little dirtier of face and coarser of language, but as good of heart as any man. Better than most lords.

tælmɑnz ɹoʊd dʒʌst əhɛd. hid pɹɑbli wɪʃ fəɹ ə naɪsɝ tævɝn ðən mæt, ə pleɪs tə dʒɔɪn ə ɡeɪm ə kɑɹdz ɹæðɝ ðən θɹoʊɪŋ daɪs. bʌt ðeɪ maɪt nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ ʌv ə tʃɔɪs. ðə vɪlədʒ wɑz ə disən saɪz, pɹɑbli wɝði ʌv biɪŋ kɔld ə taʊn, bʌt wɑz ənlaɪkli tə hæv mɔɹ ðən θɹi əɹ fɔɹ ɪnz. ðɛɹ tʃɔɪsəz wəd bi lɪməɾəd.

Talmanes rode just ahead. He'd probably wish for a nicer tavern than Mat, a place to join a game of cards rather than throwing dice. But they might not have much of a choice. The village was of decent size, probably worthy of being called a town, but was unlikely to have more than three or four inns. Their choices would be limited.

disən saɪz, mæt θɔt, ɡɹɪnɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf əz i tʊk ɔf ɪz hæɾ ən skɹætʃt ət ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd. hɪndɝstæp wəɾ oʊnli hæv θɹi əɹ fɔɹ ɪnz, ən ðət meɪɾ ɪɾ ə "smɔl" taʊn. waɪ, mæt kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən hid θɔt bɛɹlən ə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾi, ən ɪt pɹɑbli wɑzn mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðɪs hɪndɝstæp!

Decent size, Mat thought, grinning to himself as he took off his hat and scratched at the back of his head. Hinderstap would only have three or four inns, and that made it a "small" town. Why, Mat could remember when he'd thought Baerlon a large city, and it probably wasn't much larger than this Hinderstap!

ə hɔɹs pʊld ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm. tɑm wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ðət blæstəd lɛɾɝ əɡɛn. ðə læŋki ɡlimənz feɪs wɑz θɔtfəl, hɪz waɪt hɛɹ stɝɪŋ ɪn ðə bɹiz, əz i stɛɹd daʊn ət ðə wɝdz. əz ɪf i hædn ɹɛɾ əm ə θaʊzən taɪmz ɔlɹɛɾi.

A horse pulled up beside him. Thom was looking at that blasted letter again. The lanky gleeman's face was thoughtful, his white hair stirring in the breeze, as he stared down at the words. As if he hadn't read them a thousand times already.

"waɪ doʊn jə pʊt ðəɾ əweɪ?" mæt sɛd. tɑm lʊkt ʌp. ɪt hæd teɪkən səm tɔkɪŋ tə ɡɛt ðə ɡlimən tə kʌm daʊn tə ðə vɪlədʒ, bʌt tɑm niɾəd ɪt, niɾəd səm dɪstʃɹækʃən.

"Why don't you put that away?" Mat said. Thom looked up. It had taken some talking to get the gleeman to come down to the village, but Thom needed it, needed some distraction.

"aɪ min ɪt, tɑm," mæt sɛd. "aɪ noʊ jəɹ iɡɝ tə ɡoʊ fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn. bʌɾ ɪɾəl bi wiks bɪfɔɹ wi kən bɹeɪk əweɪ, ən ɹɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ðoʊz wɝdz woʊn də ɛniθɪŋ bʌt meɪk jə æŋkʃəs."

"I mean it, Thom," Mat said. "I know you're eager to go for Moiraine. But it'll be weeks before we can break away, and reading over those words won't do anything but make you anxious."

tɑm nɑɾəd ən foʊldəd ðə peɪpɝ wɪð ɹɛvɝən fɪŋɡɝz. "jɔɹ ɹaɪt, mæt. bʌɾ aɪd bɪn kæɹiɪŋ ðɪs lɛɾɝ fəɹ mʌnθs. naʊ ðəɾ aɪv ʃɛɹɾ ɪt, aɪ fil. . . . wɛl, aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə bi ɑn wɪð ɪt."

Thom nodded and folded the paper with reverent fingers. "You're right, Mat. But I'd been carrying this letter for months. Now that I've shared it, I feel. . . . Well, I just want to be on with it."

"aɪ noʊ," mæt sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən. mɔɪɹeɪn. ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. mæt ɔlmoʊs fɛlt əz ɪf i kəd si ðə bɪldɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ, lumɪŋ. ðæts wɛɹ ɪz pæθ pɔɪntəd, ən keɪɛmlɪn wɑz dʒʌst ə stɛpɪŋ-stoʊn əlɔŋ ðə weɪ. ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz stɪl əlaɪv . . . laɪt, wʌt wəd ðət min?

"I know," Mat said, looking up toward the horizon. Moiraine. The Tower of Ghenjei. Mat almost felt as if he could see the building out there, looming. That's where his path pointed, and Caemlyn was just a stepping-stone along the way. If Moiraine was still alive . . . Light, what would that mean?

haʊ wəd ɹænd ɹiækt?

How would Rand react?

ðə ɹɛskju wɑz ənʌðɝ ɹizən mæt fɛlt i niɾəd ə ɡʊd naɪt dɪsɪŋ. waɪ hæɾ i əɡɹid tə ɡoʊ wɪð tɑm ɪndə ðə taʊɝ? ðoʊz bɝnɪŋ sneɪks ən fɑksəz - hi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə si ðɛm əɡɛn.

The rescue was another reason Mat felt he needed a good night dicing. Why had he agreed to go with Thom into the tower? Those burning snakes and foxes - he had no desire to see them again.

bʌt . . . hi ɔlsoʊ kʊdn lɛt tɑm ɡoʊ əloʊn. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪnɛvɪɾəbɪlɪti tə ɪt. əz ɪf ə pɑɹɾ ə mæt hæd noʊn ɔl əlɔŋ ðəɾ i hæd tə ɡoʊ bæk ən feɪs ðoʊz kɹitʃɝz əɡɛn. ðeɪd ɡɑɾən ðə bɛɾɝ ə hɪm twaɪs naʊ, ən ði ɛlfɪn hæd taɪd stʃɹɪŋz ɝaʊn ɪz bɹeɪn wɪð ðoʊz mɛmɹiz ɪn ɪz hɛd. hi hæɾ ə dɛt tə sɛɾəl wɪð ðɛm, ðət wɑz fəɹ sɝɾən.

But . . . he also couldn't let Thom go alone. There was an inevitability to it. As if a part of Mat had known all along that he had to go back and face those creatures again. They'd gotten the better of him twice now, and the Eelfinn had tied strings around his brain with those memories in his head. He had a debt to settle with them, that was for certain.

mæt hæd lɪɾəl lʌv fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn, bʌɾ i wʊdn liv əɹ tə ðɛm, noʊ mæɾɝ ðət ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. blʌɾi æʃəz. hid pɹɑbli bi tɛmptəd tə ɹaɪɾ ɪn ən seɪv wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ðɛmsɛlvz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹæp ðɛɹ.

Mat had little love for Moiraine, but he wouldn't leave her to them, no matter that she was Aes Sedai. Bloody ashes. He'd probably be tempted to ride in and save one of the Forsaken themselves if they were trapped there.

ən . . . meɪbi wʌn wɑz. lænfɝ hæd fɔlən θɹu ðət seɪm pɔɹɾəl. bɝn hɪm, wʌt wəɾ i də ɪf i faʊn əɹ ðɛɹ? wəɾ i ɹɪli ɹɛskju hɝ əz wɛl?

And . . . maybe one was. Lanfear had fallen through that same portal. Burn him, what would he do if he found her there? Would he really rescue her as well?

jəɹ ə ful, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. nɑɾ ə hɪɹoʊ. dʒʌst ə ful.

You're a fool, Matrim Cauthon. Not a hero. Just a fool.

"wil ɡɛt tə mɔɪɹeɪn, tɑm," mæt sɛd. "ju hæv maɪ wɝd, bɝn mi. wɪl faɪn hɝ. bʌt wɪv tə si ðə bæn sʌmpleɪs seɪf, ən wi niɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. beɪl doʊmən sɛz i noʊz wɛɹ ðə taʊɝ ɪz, bʌɾ aɪ woʊn bi kʌmftəɹbəl əntɪl wi kən ɡoʊ tə səm lɑɹdʒ sɪɾi ən snɪf fəɹ ɹumɝz ən stɔɹiz əbaʊt ðɪs taʊɝ. sʌmwʌn əz tə noʊ sʌmθɪŋ. bɪsaɪdz, wɪl nid səplaɪz, ən aɪ daʊt wɪl faɪnd wʌt wi niɾ ɪn ðiz maʊntən vɪlədʒəz. wi nid tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn ɪf pɑsəbəl, ðoʊ meɪbi wɪl stɑp ət fɔɹ kɪŋz ɑn ðə weɪ."

"We'll get to Moiraine, Thom," Mat said. "You have my word, burn me. We'll find her. But we have to see the Band someplace safe, and we need information. Bayle Domon says he knows where the tower is, but I won't be comfortable until we can go to some large city and sniff for rumors and stories about this tower. Someone has to know something. Besides, we'll need supplies, and I doubt we'll find what we need in these mountain villages. We need to reach Caemlyn if possible, though maybe we'll stop at Four Kings on the way."

tɑm nɑɾəd, ðoʊ mæt kəd si hi tʃeɪft ət livɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn tʃɹæpt, biɪŋ tɔɹtʃɝɾ əɹ u noʊz wʌt. tɑmz bɹɪljən blu aɪz ɡɑɾ ə fɑɹ-ɔf lʊk tə ðɛm. waɪ dɪɾ i kɛɹ soʊ mʌtʃ? wʌt wɑz mɔɪɹeɪn tə hɪm bʌɾ ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæd kɑs ðə laɪf ə tɑmz nɛfju?

Thom nodded, though Mat could see he chafed at leaving Moiraine trapped, being tortured or who knows what. Thom's brilliant blue eyes got a far-off look to them. Why did he care so much? What was Moiraine to him but another Aes Sedai, one of those who had cost the life of Thom's nephew?

"bɝn ɪt," mæt sɛd. "wɝ nɑt səpoʊz tə bi θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt θɪŋz laɪk ðɪs, tɑm! wɝ gɑnə hæv ə ɡʊd naɪɾ ə daɪs ən læftɝ. ðɛɹəl pɹɑbli bi səm taɪm fəɹ ə sɔŋ əɹ tu əz wɛl."

"Burn it," Mat said. "We're not supposed to be thinking about things like this, Thom! We're going to have a good night of dice and laughter. There'll probably be some time for a song or two as well."

tɑm nɑɾəd, feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ laɪɾɝ. hi hæɾ ɪz hɑɹp keɪs stʃɹæp tə ðə bæk ə hɪz hɔɹs; ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd tə si hɪm oʊpən ɪɾ əɡɛn. "ju plæn tə tʃɹaɪ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ fəɹ jəɹ sʌpɝ əɡɛn, əpɹɛntəs?"

Thom nodded, face growing lighter. He had his harp case strapped to the back of his horse; it would be good to see him open it again. "You plan to try juggling for your supper again, apprentice?"

tɑm æskt, aɪz twɪŋkəlɪŋ.

Thom asked, eyes twinkling.

"bɛɾɝ ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pleɪ ðət blæstəd flut," mæt ɡɹʌmbəld. "nɛvɝ wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət ðæt. ɹænd tʊk tə ɪt ɹaɪt faɪn, ðoʊ, dɪdn hi?"

"Better than trying to play that blasted flute," Mat grumbled. "Never was very good at that. Rand took to it right fine, though, didn't he?"

kʌlɝz swɝld ɪn mæts hɛd, ɹizɑlvɪŋ tə ən ɪmədʒ ə ɹænd, sɪɾɪŋ əloʊn ɪn ə ɹum baɪ hɪmsɛlf.

Colors swirled in Mat's head, resolving to an image of Rand, sitting alone in a room by himself.

hi sæt spleɪ-lɛɡəɾ ɪn ə ɹɪtʃli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ʃɝt, ə koʊɾ ə blæk ən ɹɛd tɔst əsaɪɾ ən kɹʌmpəl nɛks tə ðə lɔɡ wɔl bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɹænd hæd wʌn hæn tə hɪz fɔɹhɛɾ əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə skwiz əweɪ ðə peɪn ʌv ə hɛdeɪk. hɪz ʌðɝ wɑz . . .

He sat splay-legged in a richly embroidered shirt, a coat of black and red tossed aside and crumpled next to the log wall beside him. Rand had one hand to his forehead as if trying to squeeze away the pain of a headache. His other was . . .

ðəɾ ɑɹm ɛndəɾ ɪn ə stʌmp. ðə fɝs taɪm mæt hæd sin ðət - ə fju wiks bæk - ɪt hæd ʃɑk hɪm. haʊ hæd ɹænd lɔs ðə hænd? ðə mæn bɛɹli simd əlaɪv, pɹɑpt ʌp laɪk ðæt, ənmoʊvɪŋ.

That arm ended in a stump. The first time Mat had seen that - a few weeks back - it had shocked him. How had Rand lost the hand? The man barely seemed alive, propped up like that, unmoving.

ðoʊ hɪz lɪps dɪd sim tə bi muvɪŋ, mʌmbəlɪŋ əɹ mʌɾɝɪŋ. laɪt! mæt θɔt. bɝn ju, wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ tə jɝsɛlf?

Though his lips did seem to be moving, mumbling or muttering. Light! Mat thought. Burn you, what are you doing to yourself?

wɛl, ət lis mæt wɑznt nɪɹ hɪm. kaʊn jəɹ fɔɹtʃənz ɪn ðæt, mæt toʊl hɪmsɛlf. laɪf hædn bɪn soʊ izi leɪtli, bʌɾ i cʊɾə bɪn stʌk nɪɹ ɹænd. ʃʊɹ, ɹænd wɑz ə fɹɛnd. bʌt mæt dɪdn min tə bi ðəɹ wən ɹænd wɛn ɪnseɪn ən kɪld ɛvɹiwʌn i nu. ðəɹ wɑz fɹɛndʃɪp, ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz stupɪɾɪti. ðeɪd faɪt təɡɛðɝ ət ðə læs bæɾəl, ʌv kɔɹs, noʊ hɛlpɪŋ ðæt. mæt dʒʌs hoʊp tə bi ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðət bæɾəlfild fɹəm ɛni seɪɾɪn-wildɪŋ mædmən.

Well, at least Mat wasn't near him. Count your fortunes in that, Mat told himself. Life hadn't been so easy lately, but he could have been stuck near Rand. Sure, Rand was a friend. But Mat didn't mean to be there when Rand went insane and killed everyone he knew. There was friendship, and then there was stupidity. They'd fight together at the Last Battle, of course, no helping that. Mat just hoped to be on the other side of that battlefield from any saidin-wielding madmen.

"ɑ, ɹænd," tɑm sɛd. "ðæt bɔɪ cʊɾə meɪɾ ə laɪf fəɹ hɪmsɛlf əz ə ɡlimən, aɪ wɔɹənt.

"Ah, Rand," Thom said. "That boy could have made a life for himself as a gleeman, I warrant.

meɪbi ivən ə pɹɑpɝ bɑɹd, ɪf hid stɑɹɾəd wən i wɑz jʌŋɡɝ."

Maybe even a proper bard, if he'd started when he was younger."

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, dɪspɛlɪŋ ðə vɪʒən. bɝn ju, ɹænd. liv mi əloʊn.

Mat shook his head, dispelling the vision. Burn you, Rand. Leave me alone.

"ðoʊz wɝ bɛɾɝ deɪz, wɝn ðeɪ, mæt?" tɑm smaɪld. "ðə θɹi ʌv ʌs, tʃɹævlɪŋ daʊn ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑɹɪnɛl."

"Those were better days, weren't they, Mat?" Thom smiled. "The three of us, traveling down the river Arinelle."

"mɹdʒɹɑl tʃeɪsɪŋ əs fəɹ ɹizənz ənnoʊn," mæt æɾəd ɡɹɪmli. ðoʊz deɪz hædn bɪn soʊ izi iðɝ. "dɑɹkfɹɛnz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stæb əs ɪn ðə bæk ɛvɹi taɪm wi tɝn ɝaʊnd."

"Myrddraal chasing us for reasons unknown," Mat added grimly. Those days hadn't been so easy either. "Darkfriends trying to stab us in the back every time we turned around."

"bɛɾɝ ðən ɡoʊləm ən fɔɹseɪkən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ʌs."

"Better than gholam and Forsaken trying to kill us."

"ðæts laɪk seɪɪŋ jəɹ ɡɹeɪtfəl tə hæv ə nus ɝaʊn jəɹ nɛk ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə sɔɹɾ ɪn jəɹ ɡʌt."

"That's like saying you're grateful to have a noose around your neck instead of a sword in your gut."

"æt lis jə kən ɪskeɪp ðə nus, mæt." tɑm nʌkəld ɪz lɔŋ, waɪt mʌstæʃ. "wʌns ðə sɔɹɾ ɪz stʌk ɪndə ju, ðɛɹz nɑt mʌtʃ jə kən də əbaʊɾ ɪt."

"At least you can escape the noose, Mat." Thom knuckled his long, white mustache. "Once the sword is stuck into you, there's not much you can do about it."

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən faʊn hɪmsɛlf læfɪŋ. hi ɹʌbd ət ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. "aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ ɹaɪɾ ət ðæt, tɑm. aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ ɹaɪt. wɛl, fəɹ tədeɪ waɪ doʊnt wi fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɔl ə ðæt? wɪl ɡoʊ bæk ən pɹitɛn θɪŋz ɑɹ laɪk ðeɪ wʌns wɝ!"

Mat hesitated, then found himself laughing. He rubbed at the scarf around his neck. "I suppose you're right at that, Thom. I suppose you're right. Well, for today why don't we forget about all of that? We'll go back and pretend things are like they once were!"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ðæts pɑsəbəl, læd."

"I don't know if that's possible, lad."

"ʃʊɹ ɪɾ ɪz," mæt sɛd stʌbɝnli.

"Sure it is," Mat said stubbornly.

"oʊ?" tɑm æskt, əmjuzd. "jɔɹ gɑnə ɡoʊ bæk tə θɪŋkɪŋ ðəɾ oʊl tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn ɪz ðə waɪzəst, moʊst wɛl tʃɹævəl mæn juv ɛvɝ noʊn? jəl pleɪ ðə ɡɔkɪŋ pɛzən əɡɛn, klɪŋɪŋ tə maɪ koʊɾ ɛvɹi taɪm wi pæs ə vɪlədʒ wɪð mɔɹ ðən wʌn ɪn ɪn ɪt?"

"Oh?" Thom asked, amused. "You're going to go back to thinking that old Thom Merrilin is the wisest, most well traveled man you've ever known? You'll play the gawking peasant again, clinging to my coat every time we pass a village with more than one inn in it?"

"hɪɹ naʊ. aɪ wɑzn soʊ bæɾ əz ɔl ðæt."

"Here now. I wasn't so bad as all that."

"aɪ heɪsən tə dɪfɝ, mæt," tɑm sɛd, tʃʌklɪŋ.

"I hasten to differ, Mat," Thom said, chuckling.

"aɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ mʌtʃ." mæt skɹætʃt əɾ ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn. "bʌɾ aɪ də ɹikɔl ðət ɹænd ən aɪ dɪd ɹaɪt wɛl fəɹ aʊɝsɛlvz æftɝ wi splɪɾ ʌp wɪð ju. wi meɪɾ ɪt tə keɪɛmlɪn, ət list. bɹɔt jəɹ fleɪmɪŋ hɑɹp bæk tə jə ənhɑɹmd, dɪdnt wi?"

"I don't remember much." Mat scratched at his head again. "But I do recall that Rand and I did right well for ourselves after we split up with you. We made it to Caemlyn, at least. Brought your flaming harp back to you unharmed, didn't we?"

"aɪ noʊɾəst ə fju nɪks ɪn ðə fɹeɪm. . . ."

"I noticed a few nicks in the frame. . . ."

"bɝn ju, nʌn ə ðæt!" mæt sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ ət hɪm. "ɹæn pɹæktəkli slɛpt wɪð ðət hɑɹp.

"Burn you, none of that!" Mat said, pointing at him. "Rand practically slept with that harp.

wʊdn θɪŋk ə sɛlɪŋ ɪt, ivən wən wi wɝ soʊ hʌŋɡɹi wiɾ əv nɔɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn buts ɪf wi hædnt niɾəd əm tə ɡɛt tə ðə nɛks taʊn." ðoʊz deɪz wɝ fʌzi tə mæt, fʊl ə hoʊlz, laɪk ən aɪɝn bʌkət lɛf tu lɔŋ tə ɹʌst. bʌɾ i hæd pis təɡɛðɝ səm θɪŋz.

Wouldn't think of selling it, even when we were so hungry we'd have gnawed on our own boots if we hadn't needed them to get to the next town." Those days were fuzzy to Mat, full of holes, like an iron bucket left too long to rust. But he had pieced together some things.

tɑm tʃʌkəld. "wi kænt ɡoʊ bæk, mæt. ðə wil əz tɝnd, fəɹ bɛɾɝ əɹ wɝs. ən ɪɾəl kip ɑn tɝnɪŋ, əz laɪts daɪ ən fɔɹəsts dɪm, stɔɹmz kɔl ən skaɪz bɹeɪk. tɝn ɪt wɪl. ðə wil ɪz nɑt hoʊp, ən ðə wil dʌz nɑt kɛɹ, ðə wil sɪmpli ɪz. bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt tɝnz, foʊk meɪ hoʊp, foʊk meɪ kɛɹ. fəɹ wɪð laɪt ðət feɪdz, ənʌðɝ wɪl ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɡɹoʊ, ən itʃ stɔɹm ðət ɹeɪdʒɪz mʌst ɪvɛntʃəwəli daɪ. əz lɔŋ əz ðə wil tɝnz. əz lɔŋ əz ɪt tɝnz. . . ."

Thom chuckled. "We can't go back, Mat. The Wheel has turned, for better or worse. And it will keep on turning, as lights die and forests dim, storms call and skies break. Turn it will. The Wheel is not hope, and the Wheel does not care, the Wheel simply is. But so long as it turns, folk may hope, folk may care. For with light that fades, another will eventually grow, and each storm that rages must eventually die. As long as the Wheel turns. As long as it turns. . . ."

mæt ɡaɪɾəd pɪps ɝaʊn ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli dip klft ɪn ðə bɹoʊkən ɹoʊdweɪ. əhɛd, tælmɑnz tʃæɾəd wɪð sɛvɹəl ə ðɛɹ ɡɑɹdz. "ðæɾ əz ðə saʊn ʌv ə sɔŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, tɑm."

Mat guided Pips around a particularly deep cleft in the broken roadway. Ahead, Talmanes chatted with several of their guards. "That has the sound of a song about it, Thom."

"aɪ," tɑm sɛd, ɔlmoʊst wɪð ə saɪ. "æn oʊld wʌn, fɝɡɑɾən baɪ moʊst. aɪv dɪskʌvɝd θɹi vɝʒənz ʌv ɪt, ɔl wɪð ðə seɪm wɝdz, sɛt tə dɪfɹən tunz. aɪ ɡɛs ði ɛɹiə hæz mi θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪt; ɪts sɛd ðət dɔɹl hɝsɛlf pɛn ði ɝɪdʒənəl poʊəm."

"Aye," Thom said, almost with a sigh. "An old one, forgotten by most. I've discovered three versions of it, all with the same words, set to different tunes. I guess the area has me thinking of it; it's said that Doreille herself penned the original poem."

"ði ɛɹiə?" mæt sɛd wɪð sɝpɹaɪz, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə θɹi-niɾəl paɪnz.

"The area?" Mat said with surprise, glancing at the three-needle pines.

tɑm nɑɾəd, θɔtfəl. "ðɪs ɹoʊɾ ɪz oʊld, mæt. eɪntʃənt. pɹɑbli wɑz hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ. lændmɑɹks laɪk ðɪs əv ə tɛndənsi tə faɪn ðɛɹ weɪ ɪndə sɔŋz ən stɔɹiz. aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs ɛɹiə ɪz wʌt wɑz wʌns kɔl ðə splɪntɝd hɪlz. ɪf ðæts tʃɹu, ðən wɝ ɪn wʌt wɑz wʌns kɔɹmændə, ɹaɪt nɪɹ ði iɡəlz ɹitʃəz. aɪ bɛt jə ɪf wi klaɪmd ə fju ʌv ðoʊz tɔlɝ hɪlz, wid faɪn oʊl fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz."

Thom nodded, thoughtful. "This road is old, Mat. Ancient. Probably was here before the Breaking. Landmarks like this have a tendency to find their way into songs and stories. I think this area is what was once called the Splintered Hills. If that's true, then we're in what was once Coremanda, right near the Eagle's Reaches. I bet you if we climbed a few of those taller hills, we'd find old fortifications."

"ænd wʌt dʌz ðəɾ əv tə də wɪð dɔɹl?" mæt æskt, ənkʌmftəbli. ʃid bɪn kwin ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl.

"And what does that have to do with Doreille?" Mat asked, uncomfortably. She'd been Queen of Aridhol.

"ʃi vɪzəɾəd hɪɹ," tɑm sɛd. "pɛn sɛvɹəl ə hɝ faɪnəs poʊəmz ɪn ði iɡəlz ɹitʃəz."

"She visited here," Thom said. "Penned several of her finest poems in the Eagle's Reaches."

bɝn mi, mæt θɔt. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd stændɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔlz ʌv ə haɪ fɔɹt, koʊld ɑn ðə maʊntəntɑp, lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɾ ə lɔŋ, twɪstɪŋ ɹoʊdweɪ, bɹoʊkən ən ʃæɾɝd, ən ən ɑɹmi ʌv mɛn wɪð vaɪəlɪt pɛnəns tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ʌp ðə hɪlsaɪɾ ɪndə ə ɹeɪn ʌv æɹoʊz. ðə splɪntɝd hɪlz. ə wʊmən ɑn ðə bælkəni. ðə kwin hɝsɛlf.

Burn me, Mat thought. I remember. He remembered standing on the walls of a high fort, cold on the mountaintop, looking down at a long, twisting roadway, broken and shattered, and an army of men with violet pennants charging up the hillside into a rain of arrows. The Splintered Hills. A woman on the balcony. The Queen herself.

hi ʃɪvɝd, bænɪʃɪŋ ðə mɛmɹi. ɑɹɪdhɔl hæd bɪn wʌn ə ði eɪntʃənt neɪʃənz ðət hæd stʊd lɔŋ əɡoʊ, wən meɪnɛðɝən hæd bɪn ə paʊɝ. ðə kæpəɾəl ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl hæɾ ənʌðɝ neɪm. ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ.

He shivered, banishing the memory. Aridhol had been one of the ancient nations that had stood long ago, when Manetheren had been a power. The capital of Aridhol had another name. Shadar Logoth.

mæt hædn fɛl ðə pʊl ə ðə ɹubi dæɡɝ ɪn ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm. hi wɑz nɪɹli bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fɝɡɛt wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn laɪk tə bi taɪd tə ɪt, ɪf ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə fɝɡɛt sətʃ ə θɪŋ. bʌt səmtaɪmz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət ɹubi, ɹɛd laɪk ɪz oʊn blʌd. ən ði oʊld lʌst, ði oʊl dɪzaɪɝ, wəd sip ɪndə hɪm əɡɛn . . .

Mat hadn't felt the pull of the ruby dagger in a very long time. He was nearly beginning to forget what it had been like to be tied to it, if it was possible to forget such a thing. But sometimes he remembered that ruby, red like his own blood. And the old lust, the old desire, would seep into him again . . .

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, fɔɹsɪŋ daʊn ðoʊz mɛmɹiz. bɝn ɪt, hi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ hɪmsɛlf!

Mat shook his head, forcing down those memories. Burn it, he was supposed to be enjoying himself!

"wʌɾ ə taɪm wiv hæd," tɑm sɛɾ aɪdli. "aɪ fil oʊl ðiz deɪz, mæt, laɪk ə feɪɾəd ɹʌɡ, hʌŋ aʊt tə dʒɹaɪ ɪn ðə wɪnd, hɪntɪŋ ə ðə kʌlɝz ɪt wʌns ʃoʊd soʊ vaɪbɹənli. səmtaɪmz, aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ɪm ɛni jus tə jə ɛnimɔɹ. jə hɑɹdli sim tə nid mi."

"What a time we've had," Thom said idly. "I feel old these days, Mat, like a faded rug, hung out to dry in the wind, hinting of the colors it once showed so vibrantly. Sometimes, I wonder if I'm any use to you anymore. You hardly seem to need me."

"wʌt? ʌv kɔɹs aɪ nid ju, tɑm!"

"What? Of course I need you, Thom!"

ði eɪdʒɪŋ ɡlimən aɪd hɪm. "ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ju, mæt, ɪz ðət jəɹ æktʃəli  ɡʊɾ ət laɪɪŋ.

The aging gleeman eyed him. "The trouble with you, Mat, is that you're actually good at lying.

ənlaɪk ðoʊz ʌðɝ tu bɔɪz."

Unlike those other two boys."

"aɪ min ɪt! bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ du. aɪ səpoʊz jə kəd ɹʌn ɔf ən tɛl stɔɹiz ən tʃɹævəl laɪk jə juz tə. bʌt θɪŋz ɝaʊn hɪɹ maɪt ɹʌn ə lɑt lɛs smuðli, ən aɪ ʃʊɹ wəd mɪs jəɹ wɪzdəm. bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ wʊd. ə mæn nidz fɹɛnz i kən tʃɹʌst, ən aɪd tʃɹʌs jə wɪð maɪ laɪf ɛni deɪ."

"I mean it! Burn me, but I do. I suppose you could run off and tell stories and travel like you used to. But things around here might run a lot less smoothly, and I sure would miss your wisdom. Burn me, but I would. A man needs friends he can trust, and I'd trust you with my life any day."

"waɪ meɪtʃɹim," tɑm sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp, aɪz ɡlɪmɝɪŋ wɪð mɝθ, "boʊlstɝɪŋ ə mænz spɪɹəts wən hiz daʊn? kənvɪnsɪŋ ɪm tə steɪ ən də wʌɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ɹæðɝ ðən ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf tə sik ædvɛntʃɝ? ðət saʊnz daʊnɹaɪt ɹispɑnsəbəl. wʌts ɡɑɾən ɪndə ju?"

"Why Matrim," Thom said, looking up, eyes glimmering with mirth, "bolstering a man's spirits when he's down? Convincing him to stay and do what is important, rather than running off to seek adventure? That sounds downright responsible. What's gotten into you?"

mæt ɡɹɪməst. "mɛɹɪdʒ, aɪ ɡɛs. bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪm nɑt gɑnə stɑp dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ əɹ ɡæmbəlɪŋ!"

Mat grimaced. "Marriage, I guess. Burn me, but I'm not going to stop drinking or gambling!"

əhɛd, tælmɑnz tɝn ɝaʊn ən ɡlænst ət mæt, ðən ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz.

Ahead, Talmanes turned around and glanced at Mat, then rolled his eyes.

tɑm læft, wɑtʃɪŋ tælmɑnz. "wɛl, læd, aɪ dɪdn min tə ɡɛt jəɹ spɪɹəts daʊn. dʒʌst aɪɾəl tɔk. aɪ stɪl əv ə fju θɪŋz aɪ kən ʃoʊ ðɪs wɝld. ɪf aɪ ɹɪli kən fɹi mɔɪɹeɪn . . . wɛl, wɪl si.

Thom laughed, watching Talmanes. "Well, lad, I didn't mean to get your spirits down. Just idle talk. I still have a few things I can show this world. If I really can free Moiraine . . . well, we'll see.

bɪsaɪdz, sʌmbɑɾi nidz tə bi hɪɹ tə wɑtʃ, ðən pʊt ðɪs ɔl tə sɔŋ, sʌmdeɪ. ðəɹ wɪl bi mɔɹ ðən wʌn bæləd ðət kʌmz fɹəm ɔl ə ðɪs."

Besides, somebody needs to be here to watch, then put this all to song, someday. There will be more than one ballad that comes from all of this."

hi tɝnd, ɹaɪflɪŋ θɹu hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. "ɑ!" hi sɛd, pʊlɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz pætʃwɝk ɡlimənz kloʊk. hi θɹu ɪɾ ɑn wɪð ə flɝɪʃ.

He turned, rifling through his saddlebags. "Ah!" he said, pulling out his patchwork gleeman's cloak. He threw it on with a flourish.

"wɛl," mæt sɛd, "wɛn jə ɹaɪɾ əbaʊɾ ʌs, jə maɪt faɪn ə fju ɡoʊl mɑɹks ɪn ɪɾ ɪf jə sɔ jəɹ weɪ tə ɪnkluɾ ə naɪs vɝs əbaʊt tælmɑnz. jə noʊ, sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ hiz wʌn aɪ ðət stɛɹz ɪn stʃɹeɪnʒ dɝɛkʃənz, ən haʊ hi ɔfən kæɹiz ðɪs sɛn əbaʊɾ ɪm wɪtʃ ɹimaɪnz wʌn ʌv ə ɡoʊt pɛn."

"Well," Mat said, "when you write about us, you might find a few gold marks in it if you saw your way to include a nice verse about Talmanes. You know, something about how he has one eye that stares in strange directions, and how he often carries this scent about him which reminds one of a goat pen."

"aɪ hɝd ðæt!" tælmɑnz kɔl fɹəm əhɛd.

"I heard that!" Talmanes called from ahead.

"aɪ mɛn jə tə!" mæt kɔl bæk.

"I meant you to!" Mat called back.

tɑm dʒʌs læft, plʌkɪŋ əɾ ɪz kloʊk, ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ɪt fəɹ bɛs dɪspleɪ. "aɪ kæn pɹɑməs ɛniθɪŋ."

Thom just laughed, plucking at his cloak, arranging it for best display. "I can't promise anything."

hi tʃʌkəl səm mɔɹ. "ðoʊ, ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd, mæt, aɪ θɪŋk əl sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ə jə wʌns wi ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə vɪlədʒ. ə ɡlimənz ɪɹz meɪ pɪk ʌp ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ðət woʊn bi spoʊkən ɪn ðə pɹɛzəns ə soʊlʒɝz."

He chuckled some more. "Though, if you don't mind, Mat, I think I'll separate from the rest of you once we get into the village. A gleeman's ears may pick up information that won't be spoken in the presence of soldiers."

"ɪnfɝmeɪʃən wəd bi naɪs," mæt sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. ðə tʃɹeɪl tɝn ʌp əhɛd; veɪnɪn sɛd ðeɪd faɪn ðə vɪlədʒ dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə tɝn. "aɪ fil əz ðoʊ aɪv bɪn tʃɹævlɪŋ θɹu ə tʌnəl fəɹ mʌnθs naʊ, wɪð noʊ saɪɾ əɹ saʊn ə ði aʊtsaɪd wɝld. bɝn mi, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi naɪs tə noʊ wɛɹ ɹænd ɪz, ɪf oʊnli tə noʊ wɛɹ nɑt tə ɡoʊ." ðə kʌlɝz spʌn, ʃoʊɪŋ ɪm ɹænd - bʌt ðə mæn wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn ə ɹum wɪð noʊ vju ʌv ði aʊtsaɪd, ɡɪvɪŋ mæt noʊ klu əz tə wɛɹ i maɪt bi.

"Information would be nice," Mat said, rubbing his chin. The trail turned up ahead; Vanin said they'd find the village just beyond the turn. "I feel as though I've been traveling through a tunnel for months now, with no sight or sound of the outside world. Burn me, but it would be nice to know where Rand is, if only to know where not to go." The colors spun, showing him Rand - but the man was standing in a room with no view of the outside, giving Mat no clue as to where he might be.

"laɪfs ðət tʌnəl moʊs taɪmz, aɪm əfɹeɪd," tɑm sɛd. "pipəl ɪkspɛkt ə ɡlimən tə bɹɪŋ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, soʊ wi pʊl ɪɾ aʊɾ ən bɹʌʃ ɪɾ ɔf fəɹ dɪspleɪ - bʌt mʌtʃ ə ðə 'nuz' wi tɛl ɪz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ bætʃ ə stɔɹiz, ɪn mɛni keɪsəz lɛs tʃɹu ðən ðə bælədz fɹəm ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ."

"Life's that tunnel most times, I'm afraid," Thom said. "People expect a gleeman to bring information, so we pull it out and brush it off for display - but much of the 'news' we tell is just another batch of stories, in many cases less true than the ballads from a thousand years ago."

mæt nɑɾəd.

Mat nodded.

"ænd," tɑm æɾəd, "aɪl si ɪf aɪ kən dɪɡ ʌp hɪns fəɹ ði ɪnkɝʒən."

"And," Thom added, "I'll see if I can dig up hints for the incursion."

ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. mæt ʃɹʌɡd. "wɝ mɔɹ laɪkli tə faɪnd wʌt wi niɾ ɪn fɔɹ kɪŋz əɹ keɪɛmlɪn."

The Tower of Ghenjei. Mat shrugged. "We're more likely to find what we need in Four Kings or Caemlyn."

"jɛs, aɪ noʊ. bʌɾ oʊlvɝ meɪd mi pɹɑməs tə tʃɛk. ɪf jə hædn sɛt noʊl tə kipɪŋ ðə bɔɪ dɪstʃɹæktəd, aɪɾ ɪkspɛk tə oʊpən əɹ sæɾəlbæɡz ən faɪn ɪm ɪn ðɛɹ. hi ɹɪli wɑntəd tə kʌm."

"Yes, I know. But Olver made me promise to check. If you hadn't set Noal to keeping the boy distracted, I'd expect to open our saddlebags and find him in there. He really wanted to come."

"ə naɪt dænsɪŋ ən ɡæmbəlɪŋ ɪz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ ə bɔɪ," mæt mʌɾɝd. "aɪ dʒʌst wɪʃ aɪ kəd tʃɹʌs ðə mɛn bæk ət kæmp nɑt tə kɝʌpt ɪm wɝs ðən ə tævɝn wʊd."

"A night dancing and gambling is no place for a boy," Mat muttered. "I just wish I could trust the men back at camp not to corrupt him worse than a tavern would."

"wɛl, hi steɪd bæk kwaɪətli ɪnʌf wʌns noʊl ɡɑɾ aʊt ðə bɔɹd." oʊlvɝ wɑz kənvɪns ðəɾ ɪf i pleɪd sneɪks ən fɑksəz ɪnʌf, hid pɪk aʊt səm sikɹət stʃɹæɾədʒi fəɹ dɪfiɾɪŋ ði æɛlfɪn ən ɛlfɪn. "ðə læd stɪl θɪŋks hiz kʌmɪŋ wɪð əs ɪndə ðə taʊɝ," tɑm sɛd mɔɹ kwaɪətli. "hi noʊz i kæn bi wʌn ə ðə θɹi, bʌɾ i plænz tə weɪɾ aʊtsaɪd fəɹ ʌs. meɪbi bɝst ɪn tə seɪv əs ɪf wi doʊn kʌm bæk sun ɪnʌf. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə bi ðəɹ wən i dɪskʌvɝz ðə tʃɹuθ."

"Well, he stayed back quietly enough once Noal got out the board." Olver was convinced that if he played Snakes and Foxes enough, he'd pick out some secret strategy for defeating the Aelfinn and Eelfinn. "The lad still thinks he's coming with us into the tower," Thom said more quietly. "He knows he can't be one of the three, but he plans to wait outside for us. Maybe burst in to save us if we don't come back soon enough. I don't want to be there when he discovers the truth."

"aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə bi ðəɹ maɪsɛlf," mæt sɛd. əhɛd, ðə tʃɹiz bɹoʊk waɪɾ ɪndə ə smɔl væli wɪð ɡɹin pæstʃɝz ɹaɪzɪŋ haɪ əlɔŋ ðə hɪlz tə ðə saɪdz. ə taʊn ə sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd bɪldɪŋz wɑz nɛsəl bɪtwin ðə sloʊps, ə maʊntən stʃɹim ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ðə mɪɾəl. ðə haʊsəz wɝ ʌv ə dip ɡɹeɪ stoʊn, itʃ wɪð ə pɹɑmənən tʃɪmni, moʊst ʌv wɪtʃ kɝld wɪð smoʊk. ðə ɹufs wɝ sləp tə dil wɪð wʌt wɝ pɹɑbli vɛɹi snoʊi wɪntɝz, ðoʊ ði oʊnli waɪt stɪl vɪzəbəl naʊ wɑz ɑn dɪstən piks. wɝkɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪzi ɑn sɛvɹəl ə ðə ɹufs ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ wɪntɝ-dæmədʒd ʃɪŋɡəlz, ən ɡoʊts ən ʃip ɡɹeɪz ðə hɪlsaɪdz, wɑtʃt oʊvɝ baɪ ʃɛpɝd bɔɪz.

"I don't intend to be there myself," Mat said. Ahead, the trees broke wide into a small valley with green pastures rising high along the hills to the sides. A town of several hundred buildings was nestled between the slopes, a mountain stream running down the middle. The houses were of a deep gray stone, each with a prominent chimney, most of which curled with smoke. The roofs were sloped to deal with what were probably very snowy winters, though the only white still visible now was on distant peaks. Workers were already busy on several of the roofs replacing winter-damaged shingles, and goats and sheep grazed the hillsides, watched over by shepherd boys.

ðəɹ wɝ ə fju aʊɝz ə laɪt ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ, ən ʌðɝ mɛn wɝkt ɑn ʃoʊpfɹʌns ən fɛnsəz.

There were a few hours of light remaining, and other men worked on shopfronts and fences.

ʌðɝz stʃɹoʊl θɹu ðə stʃɹits ə ðə vɪlədʒ, noʊ ɝdʒənsi ɪn ðɛɹ ɡeɪt. oʊvɝɔl, ðə lɪɾəl taʊn hæɾ ə ɹɪlæksɪŋ ɛɹ ə mɪkst ɪndəstʃɹi ən leɪzinəs.

Others strolled through the streets of the village, no urgency in their gait. Overall, the little town had a relaxing air of mixed industry and laziness.

mæt pʊld ʌp bɪsaɪd tælmɑnz ən ðə soʊlʒɝz. "ðæts ə naɪs saɪt," tælmɑnz noʊɾəd. "aɪ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk ɛvɹi taʊn ɪn ðə wɝld wɑz iðɝ fɔlɪŋ əpɑɹt, pækt wɪð ɹɛfjudʒiz əɹ ʌndɝ ðə θʌm ʌv ɪnveɪɾɝz. ət lis ðɪs wʌn dʌzn sim laɪkli tə vænɪʃ ɑn əs . . ."

Mat pulled up beside Talmanes and the soldiers. "That's a nice sight," Talmanes noted. "I was beginning to think every town in the world was either falling apart, packed with refugees or under the thumb of invaders. At least this one doesn't seem likely to vanish on us . . ."

"laɪt sɛn ɪt soʊ," mæt sɛd, ʃɪvɝɪŋ, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə taʊn ɪn ɔltɑɹə ðət hæd vænɪʃt. "ɛniweɪ, lɛts hoʊp ðeɪ doʊn maɪn dilɪŋ wɪð ə fju stʃɹeɪnʒɝz." hi aɪd ðə soʊlʒɝz; ɔl faɪv wɝ ɹɛdʒɹmz, əmʌŋ ðə bɛst i hæd. "θɹi ʌv jə faɪv, ɡoʊ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ səspɛk ðət ðəl wɑnə steɪ əɾ ə dɪfɹən ɪn fɹəm maɪsɛlf. wɪl miɾ ʌp ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ."

"Light send it so," Mat said, shivering, thinking of the town in Altara that had vanished. "Anyway, let's hope they don't mind dealing with a few strangers." He eyed the soldiers; all five were Redarms, among the best he had. "Three of you five, go with the Aes Sedai. I suspect that they'll want to stay at a different inn from myself. We'll meet up in the morning."

ðə soʊlʒɝz səluɾəd, ən dʒoʊlin snɪft əz ʃi pæst ɑn əɹ hɔɹs, pɔɪntɪdli nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət mæt.

The soldiers saluted, and Joline sniffed as she passed on her horse, pointedly not looking at Mat.

ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz hɛɾəd daʊn ði ɪnklaɪn ɪn ə lɪɾəl klʌstɝ, θɹi ʌv mæts soʊlʒɝz fɑloʊɪŋ.

She and the others headed down the incline in a little cluster, three of Mat's soldiers following.

"ðæt lʊks laɪk ən ɪn ðɛɹ," tɑm sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə lɑɹdʒɝ bɪldɪŋ ɑn ði istɝn saɪɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ. "jul faɪn mi ðɛɹ." hi weɪvd, ðən kɪkt ɪz maʊn ɪndə ə tʃɹɑɾ ən ɹoʊɾ ɑn əhɛd, ɡlimənz kloʊk stʃɹimɪŋ. ɝaɪvɪŋ fɝst wəd ɡɪv ɪm ðə bɛs tʃæns əɾ ə dʒɹəmæɾɪk ɛntʃɹəns.

"That looks like an inn there," Thom said, pointing toward a larger building on the eastern side of the village. "You'll find me there." He waved, then kicked his mount into a trot and rode on ahead, gleeman's cloak streaming. Arriving first would give him the best chance at a dramatic entrance.

mæt ɡlænst ət tælmɑnz, hu ʃɹʌɡd. ðə tu ʌv əm meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ daʊn ðə sloʊp wɪð tu soʊlʒɝz əz ən ɛskɔɹt. kəz ə ðə bɛn ɪn ðə ɹoʊd, ðeɪ wɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə saʊθwɛst.

Mat glanced at Talmanes, who shrugged. The two of them made their way down the slope with two soldiers as an escort. Because of the bend in the road, they were approaching from the southwest.

tə ðə nɔɹθist ə ðə vɪlədʒ, ði eɪntʃən ɹoʊdweɪ kəntɪnjud. ɪt lʊk stʃɹeɪnʒ tə hæv sətʃ ə lɑɹdʒ ɹoʊd liɾɪŋ pæst ə vɪlədʒ laɪk ðɪs, ivən ɪf ðət ɹoʊd wɑz oʊld ən bɹoʊkən. mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl kleɪm ðəɾ ɪt wəd lɛɾ əm stʃɹeɪɾ ʌp ɪndə ændɝ. ɪt wɑz tu ənivən tə bi juzd əz ə meɪdʒɝ haɪweɪ, ən ðə dɝɛkʃən ɪt lɛd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ pæs meɪdʒɝ sɪɾiz, soʊ ɪt hæd bɪn fɝɡɑɾən. mæt blɛs ðɛɹ lʌk ɪn faɪndɪŋ ɪt, ðoʊ. ðə meɪn pæsədʒəz ɪndə mʊɹændi hæd bɪn kɹaʊɾəd wɪð sintʃæn.

To the northeast of the village, the ancient roadway continued. It looked strange to have such a large road leading past a village like this, even if that road was old and broken. Master Roidelle claimed that it would lead them straight up into Andor. It was too uneven to be used as a major highway, and the direction it led no longer passed major cities, so it had been forgotten. Mat blessed their luck in finding it, though. The main passages into Murandy had been crowded with Seanchan.

əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɹɔɪdɛlz mæps, hɪndɝstæp spɛʃəlaɪzd ɪn pɹədusɪŋ ɡoʊts tʃiz ən mʌɾən fəɹ ðə vɛɹiəs taʊnz ən mænɝ lænz ɪn ðə ɹidʒən. ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz ʃəd bi juz tə aʊtsaɪɾɝz. ɪndid, sɛvɹəl bɔɪz keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðə filz ðə moʊmən ðeɪ spɑɾəd tɑm ən ɪz ɡlimənz kloʊk.

According to Roidelle's maps, Hinderstap specialized in producing goat's cheese and mutton for the various towns and manor lands in the region. The villagers should be used to outsiders. Indeed, several boys came running from the fields the moment they spotted Thom and his gleeman's cloak.

hid meɪk ə stɝ, bʌɾ ə fəmɪljɝ wʌn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ, wəd bi mɛmɝəbəl.

He'd make a stir, but a familiar one. The Aes Sedai, though, would be memorable.

ɑ, wɛl, hi θɔɾ əz i ən tælmɑnz ɹoʊd daʊn ðə ɡɹæs-laɪn ɹoʊd. hi wəd ɹɪteɪn ɪz ɡʊd hjumɝ; ðɪs taɪm, hi wəd nɑt lɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹuən ɪt.

Ah, well, he thought as he and Talmanes rode down the grass-lined road. He would retain his good humor; this time, he would not let the Aes Sedai ruin it.

baɪ ðə taɪm mæt ən tælmɑnz ɹitʃt ðə vɪlədʒ, tɑm hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡæðɝɾ ə smɔl kɹaʊd. hi stʊɾ əpɹaɪɾ ɑn ɪz sæɾəl ən dʒʌɡəl θɹi kʌlɝd bɔlz ɪn ɪz ɹaɪt hænd waɪl tɔkɪŋ ə hɪz tʃɹævəlz ɪn ðə saʊθ. ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz hɪɹ wɔɹ vɛsts ən ɡɹin kloʊks ʌv ə dip, vɛlvəɾi klɔθ. ðeɪ lʊkt wɔɹm, ðoʊ əpɑn kloʊsɝ ɪnspɛkʃən, mæt noʊɾəst ðət mɛni ʌv əm - kloʊks, vɛsts ən tʃɹaʊzɝz - hæd bɪn tɔɹn, ən kɛɹfəli mɛndɪd.

By the time Mat and Talmanes reached the village, Thom had already gathered a small crowd. He stood upright on his saddle and juggled three colored balls in his right hand while talking of his travels in the south. The villagers here wore vests and green cloaks of a deep, velvety cloth. They looked warm, though upon closer inspection, Mat noticed that many of them - cloaks, vests and trousers - had been torn, and carefully mended.

ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ə pipəl, moʊsli wɪmən, hæd ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɡʊd; mæt hæd hæf- ɪkspɛktəd ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz tə bi fɹaɪɾənd. wʌn ə ðoʊz stændɪŋ ət ðə saɪɾ ə tɑmz ɡɹup aɪd mæt ən tælmɑnz əpɹeɪzɪŋli. hi wɑz ə stɝɾi fɛloʊ, wɪð θɪk ɑɹmz ən lɪnən slivz ðət wɝ ɹoʊl tə ði ɛlboʊz dɪspaɪt ðə tʃɪl spɹɪŋ ɛɹ. hɪz ɑɹmz kɝld wɪð dɑɹk hɛɹ ðət mætʃt ɪz bɪɹɾ ən ðə lɑks ɑn ɪz hɛd.

Another group of people, mostly women, had gathered around the Aes Sedai. Good; Mat had half- expected the villagers to be frightened. One of those standing at the side of Thom's group eyed Mat and Talmanes appraisingly. He was a sturdy fellow, with thick arms and linen sleeves that were rolled to the elbows despite the chill spring air. His arms curled with dark hair that matched his beard and the locks on his head.

"ju hæv ðə lʊk ʌv ə lɔɹɾ əbaʊt ju," ðə mæn sɛd, əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ mæt.

"You have the look of a lord about you," the man said, approaching Mat.

"hiz ə pɹ - " tælmɑnz bɪɡæn bɪfɔɹ mæt kʌɾ ɪm ɔf heɪstəli.

"He's a pr - " Talmanes began before Mat cut him off hastily.

"aɪ səpoʊz aɪ də ət ðæt," mæt sɛd, kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn tælmɑnz.

"I suppose I do at that," Mat said, keeping an eye on Talmanes.

"aɪm bɑɹldən, ðə meɪɝ hɪɹ," ðə mæn sɛd, foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz. "jɔɹ wɛlkəm tə kʌm ən tʃɹeɪd. bi əwɛɹ ðət wi doʊn əv mʌtʃ tə spɛɹ."

"I'm Barlden, the mayor here," the man said, folding his arms. "You're welcome to come and trade. Be aware that we don't have much to spare."

"ʃʊɹli jə ət list əv səm tʃiz," tælmɑnz sɛd. "ðæts wʌt jə pɹədus, ɪzən ɪt?"

"Surely you at least have some cheese," Talmanes said. "That's what you produce, isn't it?"

"ɔl ðət hæzən moʊldəɾ əɹ spɔɪld ɪz niɾəd fəɹ əɹ kʌstəm," meɪɝ bɑɹldən sɛd. "ðæts dʒʌs ðə weɪ ʌv θɪŋz, ðiz deɪz." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "bʌɾ ɪf juv klɔθ əɹ kloʊðɪŋ jəl tʃɹeɪd, wi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə skɹeɪp sʌmθɪŋ ʌp tə fid jə fəɹ ðə deɪ."

"All that hasn't molded or spoiled is needed for our custom," Mayor Barlden said. "That's just the way of things, these days." He hesitated. "But if you have cloth or clothing you'll trade, we might be able to scrape something up to feed you for the day."

fiɾ əs fəɹ ə deɪ? mæt θɔt. ɔl θɝtin ʌv ʌs? hid nid tə bɹɪŋ ə wæɡoʊnloʊd bæk ət list, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ði eɪl hid pɹɑməst ɪz mɛn.

Feed us for a day? Mat thought. All thirteen of us? He'd need to bring a wagonload back at least, not to mention the ale he'd promised his men.

"ju stɪl nid tə hɪɹ əbaʊt ðə kɝfju. tʃɹeɪd, wɔɹm jʊɹsɛlvz baɪ ðə hɑɹθs fəɹ ə taɪm, bʌt noʊ ðəɾ ɔl aʊtsaɪɾɝz mʌs bi aʊɾ ə ðə taʊn baɪ naɪtfɔl."

"You still need to hear about the curfew. Trade, warm yourselves by the hearths for a time, but know that all outsiders must be out of the town by nightfall."

mæt ɡlænst ʌp ət ðə klaʊd-kʌvɝd skaɪ. "bʌt ðæts bɛɹli θɹi aʊɝz əweɪ!"

Mat glanced up at the cloud-covered sky. "But that's barely three hours away!"

"ðoʊz ɑɹ əɹ ɹulz," bɑɹldən sɛd kɝtli.

"Those are our rules," Barlden said curtly.

"ɪts ɹɪdɪkjələs," dʒoʊlin sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒ wɪmən. ʃi nʌdʒd əɹ hɔɹs ə lɪɾəl kloʊsɝ tə mæt ən tælmɑnz, hɝ wɔɹɾɝz - əz ɔlweɪz - ʃæɾoʊɪŋ hɝ. "mæstɝ bɑɹldən, wi kænɑɾ əɡɹi tə ðɪs fulɪʃ pɹoʊəbɪʃən. aɪ ʌndɝstæn jəɹ hɛzəteɪʃən dʊɹɪŋ ðiz deɪnʒɝəs taɪmz, bʌt ʃʊɹli jə kən si ðət jəɹ ɹulz ʃəd nɑɾ əplaɪ hɪɹ."

"It's ridiculous," Joline said, turning away from the village women. She nudged her horse a little closer to Mat and Talmanes, her Warders - as always - shadowing her. "Master Barlden, we cannot agree to this foolish prohibition. I understand your hesitation during these dangerous times, but surely you can see that your rules should not apply here."

ðə mæn kɛpt ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ ən sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

The man kept his arms folded and said nothing.

dʒoʊlin pɝst əɹ lɪps, ɹiɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ ɹeɪnz soʊ ðəɾ əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ wɑz pɹɑmənənli vɪzəbəl. "dʌz ðə sɪmbəl ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ min soʊ lɪɾəl ðiz deɪz?"

Joline pursed her lips, rearranging her hands on her reins so that her great serpent ring was prominently visible. "Does the symbol of the White Tower mean so little these days?"

"wi ɹɪspɛk ðə waɪt taʊɝ." bɑɹldən lʊkt ət mæt. hi wɑz waɪz. miɾɪŋ ðə ɡeɪz ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tɛndəd tə meɪk wʌnz ɹizɑlv wikən. "bʌɾ əɹ ɹulz ɑɹ stʃɹɪkt, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪm sɑɹi."

"We respect the White Tower." Barlden looked at Mat. He was wise. Meeting the gaze of an Aes Sedai tended to make one's resolve weaken. "But our rules are strict, my Lady. I'm sorry."

dʒoʊlin snɪft. "aɪ səspɛk ðət jəɹ ɪnkipɝz ɑɹ lɛs ðən sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ðɪs ɹɪkwaɪɹmənt. haʊ ɑɹ ðeɪ tə meɪk ɛnz miɾ ɪf ðeɪ kæn ɹɛn ɹumz tə tʃɹævəlɝz?"

Joline sniffed. "I suspect that your innkeepers are less than satisfied with this requirement. How are they to make ends meet if they can't rent rooms to travelers?"

"ði ɪnz ɑɹ kɑmpənseɪɾəd," ðə meɪɝ sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ. "θɹi aʊɝz. də jəɹ bɪznəs ən bi ɑn jəɹ weɪ. wi min tə bi fɹɛnli tə ɔl u pæs əɹ weɪ, bʌt wi kæn si əɹ ɹulz bɹoʊkən." wɪð ðæt, hi tɝn ən lɛft. əz i wɔkt əweɪ, hi wɑz dʒɔɪn baɪ ə smɔl ɡɹup ə bɝli mɛn, sɛvɹəl kæɹiɪŋ æksiz. nɑt θɹɛɾənɪŋli. kæʒəwəli, əz ɪf ðeɪd bɪn aʊt tʃɑpɪŋ wʊd, ən dʒʌs hæpən tə bi wɔkɪŋ θɹu taʊn. təɡɛðɝ. ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən əz ðə meɪɝ.

"The inns are compensated," the mayor said gruffly. "Three hours. Do your business and be on your way. We mean to be friendly to all who pass our way, but we can't see our rules broken." With that, he turned and left. As he walked away, he was joined by a small group of burly men, several carrying axes. Not threateningly. Casually, as if they'd been out chopping wood, and just happened to be walking through town. Together. In the same direction as the mayor.

"aɪ ʃəd seɪ ðɪs ɪz kwaɪt ðə wɛlkəm," tælmɑnz mʌɾɝd.

"I should say this is quite the welcome," Talmanes muttered.

mæt nɑɾəd. ət ðət moʊmənt, ðə daɪs stɑɹɾəd ɹætlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd. bɝn ɪt! hi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ nɛvɝ ɛni hɛlp ɛniweɪ. "lɛts ɡoʊ faɪn ə tævɝn," hi sɛd, hilɪŋ pɪps fɔɹwɝd.

Mat nodded. At that moment, the dice started rattling in his head. Burn it! He decided to ignore them. They were never any help anyway. "Let's go find a tavern," he said, heeling Pips forward.

"stɪl dɪtɝmən tə meɪk ə naɪɾ ʌv ɪt, ɛ?" tælmɑnz sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ əz i dʒɔɪn mæt.

"Still determined to make a night of it, eh?" Talmanes said, smiling as he joined Mat.

"wil si," mæt sɛd, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðoʊz daɪs dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf. "wil si."

"We'll see," Mat said, listening to those dice despite himself. "We'll see."

mæt spɑɾəd θɹi ɪnz ɑn ɪz ɪnɪʃəl ɹaɪd θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn ət ði ɛn ə ðə meɪn θɝoʊfɛɹ, ən ɪt hæd tu bɹaɪt læntɝnz bɝnɪŋ aʊt fɹʌnt, ivən ðoʊ naɪt hædn jɛt fɔlən.

Mat spotted three inns on his initial ride through the village. There was one at the end of the main thoroughfare, and it had two bright lanterns burning out front, even though night hadn't yet fallen.

ðoʊz waɪtwɑʃt wɔlz ən klin ɡlæs wɪndoʊz wəd dʒɹɔ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪk mɔθs tə ə fleɪm.

Those whitewashed walls and clean glass windows would draw the Aes Sedai like moths to a flame.

ðət wəd bi ði ɪn fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ mɝtʃəns ən dɪɡnətɛɹiz ənfɔɹtʃənəɾ ɪnʌf tə faɪn ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ðiz hɪlz.

That would be the inn for traveling merchants and dignitaries unfortunate enough to find themselves in these hills.

bʌɾ aʊtsaɪɾɝz kʊdn steɪ ðə naɪt naʊ. haʊ lɔŋ hæd ðət pɹoʊəbɪʃən bɪn ɪn pleɪs? haʊ dɪd ðiz ɪnz meɪnteɪn ðɛmsɛlvz? ðeɪ kəd stɪl pɹəvaɪɾ ə bæθ ən mil, bʌt wɪθaʊt ɹɛntɪŋ ɹumz. . . .

But outsiders couldn't stay the night now. How long had that prohibition been in place? How did these inns maintain themselves? They could still provide a bath and meal, but without renting rooms. . . .

mæt dɪdn baɪ ðə meɪɝz kɑmɛn əbaʊɾ ɪnz biɪŋ "kɑmpənseɪɾəd." ɪf ðeɪ wɝn duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl fəɹ ðə vɪlədʒ, waɪ peɪ ðɛm? ɪt wɑz dʒʌs pleɪn ɑd.

Mat didn't buy the mayor's comment about inns being "compensated." If they weren't doing anything useful for the village, why pay them? It was just plain odd.

ɛniweɪ, mæt dɪdn hɛd fəɹ ðə naɪs ɪn, nɔɹ ðə wʌn tɑm hæd tʃoʊzən. ðət wʌn wɑzn ɑn ðə meɪn ɹoʊd, bʌt wɑz ɑn ə waɪd stʃɹit dʒʌs tə ðə nɔɹθist. ɪt wəd sɝv ði ævɝɪdʒ vɪzəɾɝ, ɹɪspɛktəbəl mɛn ən wɪmən u dɪdn laɪk tə spɛnd wʌt ðeɪ dɪdn əv tə. ðə bɪldɪŋ wɑz wɛl kɛɹd fɔɹ; ðə bɛdz wəd bi klin, ən ðə milz sæɾəsfæktʃɹi. ðə loʊkəlz wəd vɪzət fəɹ dʒɹɪŋks ɑn əkeɪʒən, moʊsli wən ðeɪ fɛl ðət ðɛɹ waɪvz wɝ kipɪŋ ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn ðɛm.

Anyway, Mat didn't head for the nice inn, nor the one Thom had chosen. That one wasn't on the main road, but was on a wide street just to the northeast. It would serve the average visitor, respectable men and women who didn't like to spend what they didn't have to. The building was well cared for; the beds would be clean, and the meals satisfactory. The locals would visit for drinks on occasion, mostly when they felt that their wives were keeping a close eye on them.

ðə læst ɪn wʊɾə bɪn ðə moʊs dɪfəkəl tə faɪnd, hæd mæt nɑt noʊn wɛɹ tə lʊk fəɹ ɪt. ɪt wɑz θɹi stʃɹits aʊt fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ, ɪn ðə bæk wɛs kɔɹnɝ ə ðə vɪlədʒ. noʊ saɪn hʌŋ aʊt fɹʌnt;

The last inn would have been the most difficult to find, had Mat not known where to look for it. It was three streets out from the center, in the back west corner of the village. No sign hung out front;

dʒʌst ə wʊɾən bɔɹd kɑɹvd wɪð wʌt lʊk laɪk ə dʒɹʌŋkən hɔɹs ðət sæɾ ɪnsaɪd wʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz. nʌn ə ðoʊz wɪndoʊz hæd ɡlæs.

just a wooden board carved with what looked like a drunken horse that sat inside one of the windows. None of those windows had glass.

laɪɾ ən læftɝ keɪm fɹəm ɪnsaɪd. moʊst aʊtsaɪɾɝz wʊɾə bɪn meɪɾ ənkʌmftəɹbəl baɪ ðə læk ʌv ən ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ saɪn ən stʃɹit læntɝnz nɪɹ ðɪs ɪn. ɪt wɑz ɹɪli mɔɹ ʌv ə tævɝn ðən ən ɪn; mæt daʊɾɪd ɪf ɪt hæɾ ɛvɝ hɛld ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ə fju pæləts ɪn ðə bæk ðət wʌn kəd ɹɛn fəɹ ə kɑpɝ. ðɪs wɑz ðə pleɪs fəɹ wɝkɪŋ loʊkəlz tə ɹɪlæks. wɪð ivnɪŋ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, mɛni wəɾ əv ɔlɹɛɾi meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ hɪɹ. ɪt wɑz ə pleɪs fəɹ kəmjunəɾi ən fəɹ ɹilækseɪʃən, ə pleɪs fəɹ smoʊkɪŋ ə pɪntʃ ə təbæk wɪð jəɹ fɹɛnz. ən fəɹ θɹoʊɪŋ ə fju ɡeɪmz ə daɪs.

Light and laughter came from inside. Most outsiders would have been made uncomfortable by the lack of an inviting sign and street lanterns near this inn. It was really more of a tavern than an inn; Mat doubted if it had ever held anything other than a few pallets in the back that one could rent for a copper. This was the place for working locals to relax. With evening approaching, many would have already made their way here. It was a place for community and for relaxation, a place for smoking a pinch of tabac with your friends. And for throwing a few games of dice.

mæt smaɪld ən dɪsmaʊntɪd, ðən hɪtʃt pɪps tə ðə poʊst aʊtsaɪd.

Mat smiled and dismounted, then hitched Pips to the post outside.

tælmɑnz saɪd. "ju ɹilaɪz ðət ðeɪ pɹɑbli wɔɾɝ ðɛɹ dʒɹɪŋks."

Talmanes sighed. "You realize that they probably water their drinks."

"ðɛn wɪl əv tə ɔɹɾɝ twaɪs əz mɛni," mæt sɛd, ənduɪŋ ə fju bæɡz ə kɔɪnz fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl ən stʌfɪŋ əm ɪn pɑkəts ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz koʊt. hi dʒɛstʃɝd fəɹ ɪz soʊlʒɝz tə steɪ ən ɡɑɹd ðə hɔɹsəz.

"Then we'll have to order twice as many," Mat said, undoing a few bags of coins from his saddle and stuffing them in pockets inside his coat. He gestured for his soldiers to stay and guard the horses.
