ðə pæk ænəməl kæɹiɾ ə kɔɪn tʃɛst. ɪt kənteɪn mæts pɝsənəl stæʃ: hi wʊdn ɹɪsk ðə bænz weɪdʒəz ɑn ɡæmbəlɪŋ.

The pack animal carried a coin chest. It contained Mat's personal stash: he wouldn't risk the Band's wages on gambling.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn," tælmɑnz sɛd. "bʌt jə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ aɪm gɑnə meɪk sɝɾən ðət jə ən aɪ ɡoʊ tə ə pɹɑpɝ tævɝn wʌns wi ɹitʃ fɔɹ kɪŋz. əl əv jə ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd jɛt, mæt. jəɹ ə pɹɪns naʊ.

"All right, then," Talmanes said. "But you realize that I'm going to make certain that you and I go to a proper tavern once we reach Four Kings. I'll have you educated yet, Mat. You're a prince now.

jəl nid - "

You'll need - "

mæt hɛld ʌp ə hænd, kʌɾɪŋ tælmɑnz ɔf. ðən i pɔɪntəɾ ət ðə poʊst. tælmɑnz saɪɾ əɡɛn ən slɪd fɹi ʌv ðə sæɾəl, ðən hɪtʃt ɪz hɔɹs. mæt stɛpt ʌp tə ðə tævɝn dɔɹ, tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ən ɛntɝd.

Mat held up a hand, cutting Talmanes off. Then he pointed at the post. Talmanes sighed again and slid free of the saddle, then hitched his horse. Mat stepped up to the tavern door, took a deep breath, and entered.

mɛn kɹaʊɾəd ɝaʊn teɪbəlz, ðɛɹ kloʊks dʒɹeɪpt oʊvɝ tʃɛɹz əɹ hʌŋ ɑn pɛɡz, ðɛɹ ɹɪpt ən ɹisun vɛsts ənbʌɾənd, ðɛɹ slivz ɹoʊld ʌp. waɪ dɪd pipəl hɪɹ wɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ ðət wɑz wʌns soʊ naɪs, jɛt naʊ tɔɹn ən pætʃt? ðeɪ hæd plɛnti ʌv ʃip, ən ʃəd ðɛɹfɔɹ əv wʊl tə spɛɹ.

Men crowded around tables, their cloaks draped over chairs or hung on pegs, their ripped and resewn vests unbuttoned, their sleeves rolled up. Why did people here wear clothing that was once so nice, yet now torn and patched? They had plenty of sheep, and should therefore have wool to spare.

mæt ɪɡnɔɹd ði ɑɾəti fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ðə mɛn ɪn ðɪs pleɪs pleɪɾ ət daɪs, dʒɹæŋk mʌɡz ʌv eɪl ɔf ə stɪki teɪbəlz, ən slæpt ət ðə bæksaɪdz ə pæsɪŋ bɑɹmeɪdz. ðeɪ simd ɪɡzɔstəd, mɛni ʌv ðɛɹ aɪz dʒɹupɪŋ wɪð fətiɡ. bʌt ðət wɑz tə bi ɪkspɛktəɾ æftɝ ə deɪz wɝk. dɪspaɪt ðə taɪɝɾ aɪz, ðəɹ wɑz ən ɔlmoʊs pælpəbəl tʃæɾɝ ɪn ðə ɹum, vɔɪsəz oʊvɝlæpɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn loʊ, ɹʌmbəlɪŋ mɝmɝz. ə fju pipəl lʊkt ʌp əz mæt ɛntɝd, ən səm ə ðɛm fɹaʊn əɾ ɪz naɪs kloʊðɪŋ, bʌt moʊs pipəl peɪɾ ɪm noʊ hid.

Mat ignored the oddity for the moment. The men in this place played at dice, drank mugs of ale off of sticky tables, and slapped at the backsides of passing barmaids. They seemed exhausted, many of their eyes drooping with fatigue. But that was to be expected after a day's work. Despite the tired eyes, there was an almost palpable chatter in the room, voices overlapping one another in low, rumbling murmurs. A few people looked up as Mat entered, and some of them frowned at his nice clothing, but most people paid him no heed.

tælmɑnz fɑloʊd ɹɪlʌktənli, bʌɾ i wɑzn ðə taɪp ə noʊbəlmən u maɪndəd ɹʌbɪŋ ʃoʊldɝz wɪð ðoʊz ə loʊɝ steɪʃən. hid vɪzəɾəd ɪz ʃɛɹ ə siɾi tævɝnz ɪn ɪz taɪm, ivən ɪf i hæd teɪkən tə kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊt mæts tʃɔɪsəz. ən soʊ tælmɑnz wɑz əz kwɪk əz mæt tə pʊl ə tʃɛɹ ʌp tə ə teɪbəl wɛɹ ə fju mɛn ɔlɹɛɾi sæt. mæt smaɪl bɹɔdli ən flæʃt ɡoʊld, tɔsɪŋ ɪt tə ðə pæsɪŋ bɑɹmeɪɾ ən dɪmændɪŋ səm dʒɹɪŋks. ðət ɡɑt səm ətɛnʃən, boʊθ fɹəm ðoʊz ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl ən fɹəm tælmɑnz.

Talmanes followed reluctantly, but he wasn't the type of nobleman who minded rubbing shoulders with those of lower station. He'd visited his share of seedy taverns in his time, even if he had taken to complaining about Mat's choices. And so Talmanes was as quick as Mat to pull a chair up to a table where a few men already sat. Mat smiled broadly and flashed gold, tossing it to the passing barmaid and demanding some drinks. That got some attention, both from those around the table and from Talmanes.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ," tælmɑnz hɪst, linɪŋ təwɔɹd mæt. "ju wɑnə si əs slɪɾ oʊpən ðə moʊmənt wi stʌmbəl aʊɾ ə hɪɹ?"

"What are you doing," Talmanes hissed, leaning toward Mat. "You want to see us slit open the moment we stumble out of here?"

mæt dʒʌst smaɪld. wʌn ə ðə nɪɹbaɪ teɪbəlz hæɾ ə daɪs ɡeɪm ɡoʊɪŋ. lʊk laɪk kæts pɔ - ɔɹ, ət list, ðæts wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn kɔl ðə naɪt mæt hæd fɝs bɪn tɔɾ ɪt. ðeɪ kɔld ɪt θɝd dʒɛm ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən hid hɝɾ ɪt kɔl fɛðɝz əlɔft ɪn kɛɹhin. ɪt wɑz ðə pɝfəkt ɡeɪm fəɹ ɪz pɝpəsəz. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn dɪsɝ ɪn ðə ɡeɪm, wɪð ðə kɹaʊɾ ʌv ɔnlʊkɝz bɛɾɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ fəɹ ɪz tɔsɪz.

Mat just smiled. One of the nearby tables had a dice game going. Looked like Cat's Paw - or, at least, that's what it had been called the night Mat had first been taught it. They called it Third Gem in Ebou Dar, and he'd heard it called Feathers Aloft in Cairhien. It was the perfect game for his purposes. There was only one dicer in the game, with the crowd of onlookers betting against or for his tosses.

mæt tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən pʊld ɪz tʃɛɹ oʊvɝ tə ðə teɪbəl, snæpɪŋ ə ɡoʊl kɹaʊn ɑntu ðə wʊd dɝɛkli ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ə wɛt ɹɪŋ ʌv eɪl meɪd baɪ ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə mʌɡ, naʊ hɛl baɪ ə ʃɔɹt fɛloʊ hud lɔs moʊst ə hɪz maʊzi hɛɹ, bʌt wʌɾ i dɪɾ əv hʌŋ lɔŋ daʊn ɝaʊn ɪz kɑlɝ. hi ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊkt ɑn ɪz eɪl.

Mat took a deep breath, then pulled his chair over to the table, snapping a gold crown onto the wood directly in the center of a wet ring of ale made by the bottom of a mug, now held by a short fellow who'd lost most of his mousy hair, but what he did have hung long down around his collar. He almost choked on his ale.

"kɛɹ ɪf aɪ meɪk ə θɹoʊ?" mæt sɛd tə ðə teɪbəlz ɑkjəpəns.

"Care if I make a throw?" Mat said to the table's occupants.

"aɪ . . . doʊnt noʊ ɪf wi kən mætʃ ðæt," sɛɾ ə mæn wɪð ə ʃɔɹt blæk bɪɹd. "lɔɹd," hi æɾəd bɪleɪɾədli.

"I . . . don't know if we can match that," said a man with a short black beard. "M'lord," he added belatedly.

"maɪ ɡoʊld əɡɛns jəɹ sɪlvɝ," mæt sɛd laɪtli. "aɪ hævən hæɾ ə ɡʊd ɡeɪm ə daɪs ɪn eɪdʒəz."

"My gold against your silver," Mat said lightly. "I haven't had a good game of dice in ages."

tælmɑnz pʊld ɪz tʃɛɹ oʊvɝ, ɪntʃɹəstəd. hid sin mæt də ðɪs bɪfɔɹ, pʊɾɪŋ daʊn ɡoʊl kɔɪnz ən wɪnɪŋ sɪlvɝz. mæts lʌk meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ðə dɪfɝəns, ən i ɔlweɪz keɪm aʊt fɑɹ əhɛd.

Talmanes pulled his chair over, interested. He'd seen Mat do this before, putting down gold coins and winning silvers. Mat's luck made up for the difference, and he always came out far ahead.

səmtaɪmz i kəd kʌm aʊɾ əhɛd pleɪɪŋ ɡoʊl fəɹ kɑpɝz. ðət dɪdn meɪk ɪm mʌtʃ mʌni. ɪɾ oʊnli tʊk soʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə mɛn ɪnvɑlvd iðɝ ɹæn aʊɾ ə kɔɪn əɹ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə stɑp pleɪɪŋ. ən mæt wəd bi lɛft wɪð ə hændfʊl ə sɪlvɝz ən noʊbɑdi tə daɪs wɪð.

Sometimes he could come out ahead playing gold for coppers. That didn't make him much money. It only took so long before the men involved either ran out of coin or decided to stop playing. And Mat would be left with a handful of silvers and nobody to dice with.

ðət wʊdn hɛlp. ði ɑɹmi hæd plɛnti ʌv kɔɪn. ɪt niɾəd fud, ən soʊ ɪt wɑz taɪm tə tʃɹaɪ sʌmθɪŋ dɪfɹənt. sɛvɹəl ə ðə mɛn sɛt daʊn sɪlvɝ kɔɪnz. mæt ʃʊk ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hænz, ðən tɔst. blɛsədli, ðə daɪs keɪm ʌp wɪð wʌn ʃoʊɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl pɪp ən ði ʌðɝ ʃoʊɪŋ tu. ən ɪnstən lɔs.

That wouldn't help. The army had plenty of coin. It needed food, and so it was time to try something different. Several of the men set down silver coins. Mat shook the dice in his hands, then tossed. Blessedly, the dice came up with one showing a single pip and the other showing two. An instant loss.

tælmɑnz blɪŋkt, ən ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl ɡlænst ət mæt, lʊkɪŋ ʃəɡɹɪnd - əz ɪf ɪmbɛɹəs tə hæv bɛɾ əɡɛnst ə lɔɹɾ u ɑbviəsli wɑzn ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə luz. ðət wɑz ən izi weɪ tə ɡɛt wʌnsɛlf ɪn tʃɹʌbəl.

Talmanes blinked, and the men around the table glanced at Mat, looking chagrined - as if embarrassed to have bet against a lord who obviously wasn't expecting to lose. That was an easy way to get oneself in trouble.

"wɛl, lʊk ət ðæt," mæt sɛd. "ɡɛs jə wɪn. ɪts jʊɹz." hi ɹoʊl ðə ɡoʊl kɹaʊn tə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə teɪbəl, tə bi splɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə mɛn u hæd bɛɾ əɡɛns hɪm, əz pɝ ðə ɹulz.

"Well, look at that," Mat said. "Guess you win. It's yours." He rolled the gold crown to the center of the table, to be split among the men who had bet against him, as per the rules.

"haʊ əbaʊɾ ənʌðɝ?" mæt sɛd, slæpɪŋ daʊn tu ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ teɪkɝz ðɪs taɪm. əɡɛn, hi θɹu ən lɔst, nɪɹli sɛndɪŋ tælmɑnz ɪndə ə tʃoʊkɪŋ fɪt. mæt hæd lɔs θɹoʊz bɪfɔɹ  - ɪt hæpənd, ivən tə hɪm. bʌt tu θɹoʊz ɪn ə ɹoʊ?

"How about another?" Mat said, slapping down two gold crowns. There were more takers this time. Again, he threw and lost, nearly sending Talmanes into a choking fit. Mat had lost throws before  - it happened, even to him. But two throws in a row?

hi sɛn ðə tu kɹaʊnz ɹoʊlɪŋ, ən ðən i pʊld aʊt fɔɹ. tælmɑnz pleɪst ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm.

He sent the two crowns rolling, and then he pulled out four. Talmanes placed a hand on his arm.

"noʊ əfɛns, mæt," ðə mæn sɛɾ ɪn ə kwaɪət vɔɪs. "bʌt meɪbi jə ʃəd stɑp. ɛvɹiwʌn əz ən ɔf naɪt. lɛts fɪnɪʃ əɹ dʒɹɪŋks ən ɡoʊ baɪ wʌt səplaɪz wi kən bɪfɔɹ naɪt fɔlz."

"No offense, Mat," the man said in a quiet voice. "But maybe you should stop. Everyone has an off night. Let's finish our drinks and go buy what supplies we can before night falls."

mæt dʒʌst smaɪld ən wɑtʃt əz ðə bɛts paɪld ʌp əɡɛnst ɪz fɔɹ kɔɪnz. hi hæd tə leɪ daʊn ə fɪfθ, sɪns soʊ mɛni pipəl wɑntəɾ ɪn ɑn ðə tɔs. hi ɪɡnɔɹd tælmɑnz ən θɹu, luzɪŋ jɛɾ əɡɛn.

Mat just smiled and watched as the bets piled up against his four coins. He had to lay down a fifth, since so many people wanted in on the toss. He ignored Talmanes and threw, losing yet again.

tælmɑnz ɡɹoʊnd, ðən ɹitʃt oʊvɝ ən tʊk ə mʌɡ fɹəm ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl, hu hæd faɪnəli ɝaɪv tə fɪl mæts ɔɹɾɝ.

Talmanes groaned, then reached over and took a mug from the serving girl, who had finally arrived to fill Mat's order.

"doʊn lʊk soʊ ɡɹɪm," mæt sɛd sɔfli, hɛftɪŋ ðə paʊtʃ ɪn ɪz hæn əz i ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz oʊn mʌɡ. "ðɪs ɪz wʌɾ aɪ wɑntəd."

"Don't look so grim," Mat said softly, hefting the pouch in his hand as he reached for his own mug. "This is what I wanted."

tælmɑnz ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz mʌɡ.

Talmanes raised an eyebrow, lowering his mug.

mæt sɛd, "aɪ kən luz wən aɪ wɑn tə, ɪf ɪts fəɹ ðə bɛst."

Mat said, "I can lose when I want to, if it's for the best."

"haʊ kən luzɪŋ bi fəɹ ðə bɛst?" tælmɑnz æskt, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mɛn ɑɹɡju əbaʊt haʊ tə dɪvaɪd mæts ɡoʊld.

"How can losing be for the best?" Talmanes asked, watching the men argue about how to divide Mat's gold.

"weɪt." mæt tʊk ə slɝp ʌv eɪl. ɪt wɑz əz wɔɾɝd-daʊn əz tælmɑnz hæd fɪɹd. mæt tɝn bæk tə ðə teɪbəl, kaʊntɪŋ aʊɾ ə fju mɔɹ ɡoʊl kɔɪnz.

"Wait." Mat took a slurp of ale. It was as watered-down as Talmanes had feared. Mat turned back to the table, counting out a few more gold coins.

əz ðə taɪm pæst, mɔɹ ən mɔɹ pipəl bɪɡæn ɡæðɝɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl. mæt meɪd ʃʊɹ tə wɪn ə fju tɔsɪz - dʒʌst əz i hæd tə luz ə bɪt wən spɛndɪŋ ə naɪt wɪnɪŋ, hi dɪdnt wɑnə ɝaʊz ɛni səspɪʃənz əbaʊɾ ɪz luzɪŋ stʃɹik. jɛt bɪt baɪ bɪt, ðə kɔɪnz ɪn ɪz paʊtʃəz ɛndəɾ ʌp ɪn ðə hænz ə ðə mɛn pleɪɪŋ əɡɛns hɪm. bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ɔl wɑz saɪlən ɪn ðə tævɝn, mɛn kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊn mæt ən weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝn tə bɛɾ əɡɛns hɪm. sʌnz ən fɹɛnz hæd ɹʌn tə ɡɹæb ðɛɹ fɑðɝz ən kʌzənz, dʒɹæɡɪŋ əm tə ðə tɪpsi ɡɛldɪŋ - əz ði ɪn wɑz kɔld.

As the time passed, more and more people began gathering around the table. Mat made sure to win a few tosses - just as he had to lose a bit when spending a night winning, he didn't want to arouse any suspicions about his losing streak. Yet bit by bit, the coins in his pouches ended up in the hands of the men playing against him. Before long, all was silent in the tavern, men crowding around Mat and waiting their turn to bet against him. Sons and friends had run to grab their fathers and cousins, dragging them to The Tipsy Gelding - as the inn was called.

ət wʌn pɔɪnt - dʊɹɪŋ ə bɹeɪk ɪn ðə θɹoʊz waɪl mæt wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ mʌɡ ʌv eɪl -  tælmɑnz pʊld ɪm əsaɪd. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs, mæt," ðə wɪɹi mæn sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs, linɪŋ ɪn.

At one point - during a break in the throws while Mat was waiting for another mug of ale -  Talmanes pulled him aside. "I don't like this, Mat," the wiry man said in a low voice, leaning in.

swɛt hæd lɔŋ sɪns stʃɹik ðə paʊɾɝ ɑn ɪz ʃeɪv fɔɹhɛd, ən hid waɪpt ɪɾ əweɪ, livɪŋ ðə skɪn bɛɹ.

Sweat had long since streaked the powder on his shaved forehead, and he'd wiped it away, leaving the skin bare.

"aɪ toʊl ju." mæt tʊk ə swɪɡ ʌv wɔɾɝi eɪl. "aɪ noʊ wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ." mɛn tʃɪɹd tə ðə saɪɾ əz wʌn ə ðɛm dʒɹæŋk θɹi mʌɡz, wʌn æftɝ ənʌðɝ. ði ɛɹ smɛlt ə swɛɾ ən mʌɾi eɪl, spɪl tə ðə wʊd flɔɹ ðən tʃɹæmpəl baɪ ðə buts ə ðoʊz ɝaɪvɪŋ fɹəm ðə pæstʃɝz.

"I told you." Mat took a swig of watery ale. "I know what I'm doing." Men cheered to the side as one of them drank three mugs, one after another. The air smelt of sweat and muddy ale, spilled to the wood floor then trampled by the boots of those arriving from the pastures.

"nɑt ðæt," tælmɑnz sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə tʃɪɹɪŋ mɛn. "ju kən weɪs jəɹ kɔɪn ɪf jə wɑnt, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə spɛɹ ə fju kɔɪnz tə baɪ mi ə dʒɹɪŋk naʊ ən ðɛn. ðæts nɑt wʌts bɑðɝɪŋ mi, nɑɾ ɛnimɔɹ."

"Not that," Talmanes said, glancing at the cheering men. "You can waste your coin if you want, so long as you spare a few coins to buy me a drink now and then. That's not what's bothering me, not anymore."

mæt fɹaʊnd. "wʌt?"

Mat frowned. "What?"

"sʌmθɪŋ filz ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ðiz foʊk, mæt." tælmɑnz spoʊk vɛɹi sɔfli, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "waɪl juv bɪn pleɪɪŋ, aɪv bɪn tɔkɪŋ tə ðɛm. ðeɪ doʊn kɛɹ əbaʊt ðə wɝld.

"Something feels wrong about these folk, Mat." Talmanes spoke very softly, glancing over his shoulder. "While you've been playing, I've been talking to them. They don't care about the world.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðə sintʃæn, nʌθɪŋ. nɑɾ ə kɛɹ."

The Dragon Reborn, the Seanchan, nothing. Not a care."

"soʊ?" mæt sɛd. "ðeɪɹ sɪmpəl foʊk."

"So?" Mat said. "They're simple folk."

"sɪmpəl foʊk ʃəd wɝi ivən mɔɹ," tælmɑnz sɛd. "ðeɪɹ tʃɹæp hɪɹ bɪtwin ɡæðɝɪŋ ɑɹmiz. bʌt ðiz dʒʌst ʃɹʌɡ wən aɪ tɔk, ðən dʒɹɪŋk səm mɔɹ. ɪts əz ɪf ðəɹ . . . ðəɹ tu foʊkəst ɑn ðɛɹ ɹɛvəlɹi. əz ɪf ɪts ɔl ðət mæɾɝz tə ðɛm."

"Simple folk should worry even more," Talmanes said. "They're trapped here between gathering armies. But these just shrug when I talk, then drink some more. It's as if they're . . . they're too focused on their revelry. As if it's all that matters to them."

"ðɛn ðəɹ pɝfəkt," mæt sɛd.

"Then they're perfect," Mat said.

"ɪɾəl bi dɑɹk sun," tælmɑnz sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə wɪndoʊ. "wiv juzd ən aʊɝ, pɹɑbli mɔɹ. meɪbi wi ʃəd - "

"It'll be dark soon," Talmanes said, glancing at the window. "We've used an hour, probably more. Maybe we should - "

ət ðət moʊmənt, ðə dɔɹ ə ði ɪn slæmd oʊpən ən ðə bɝli meɪɝ ɛntɝd, əkʌmpənid baɪ ðə mɛn u hæd dʒɔɪn ɪm ɝliɝ, ɔlðoʊ ðeɪd lɛf ðɛɹ æksiz bɪhaɪnd. ðeɪ dɪdn lʊk pliz tə faɪn hæf ðə vɪlədʒ ɪnsaɪd ðə tævɝn ɡæmbəlɪŋ wɪð mæt.

At that moment, the door of the inn slammed open and the burly mayor entered, accompanied by the men who had joined him earlier, although they'd left their axes behind. They didn't look pleased to find half the village inside the tavern gambling with Mat.

"mæt," tælmɑnz bɪɡæn əɡɛn.

"Mat," Talmanes began again.

mæt ɹeɪzd ə hænd, kʌɾɪŋ ɪm ɔf. "ðɪs ɪz wʌt wiv bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ."

Mat raised a hand, cutting him off. "This is what we've been waiting for."

"ɪɾ ɪz?" tælmɑnz æskt.

"It is?" Talmanes asked.

mæt tɝn bæk tə ðə dɪsɪŋ teɪbəl, smaɪlɪŋ. hid ɡɔn θɹu moʊst ə hɪz bæɡz ə kɔɪnz, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə fju mɔɹ θɹoʊz - nɑt kaʊntɪŋ wʌt hid bɹɔɾ əlɔŋ aʊtsaɪd, ʌv kɔɹs. hi pɪkt ʌp ðə daɪs ən kaʊntəɾ aʊt səm ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz, ən ðə kɹaʊd bɪɡæn tə θɹoʊ daʊn kɔɪnz ə ðɛɹ oʊn - mɛni ʌv wɪtʃ, baɪ naʊ, wɝ ɡoʊld wʌnz ðeɪd wʌn fɹəm mæt.

Mat turned back to the dicing table, smiling. He'd gone through most of his bags of coins, but he had enough for a few more throws - not counting what he'd brought along outside, of course. He picked up the dice and counted out some gold crowns, and the crowd began to throw down coins of their own - many of which, by now, were gold ones they'd won from Mat.

hi tɔst ən lɔst, kɑzɪŋ ə ɹɔɹ ʌv ɪksaɪtmən fɹəm ðoʊz wɑtʃɪŋ. bɑɹldən lʊkt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə tɔs mæt aʊt - ɪt wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ leɪt, ən sʌnsɛt kʊdn bi fɑɹ ɔf - bʌt ðə mæn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd wən i sɔ mæt pʊl aʊɾ ənʌðɝ hændfʊl ʌv ɡoʊl kɔɪnz. ɡɹid nɪbəld ɛvɹi mæn, ən stʃɹɪkt "ɹulz"

He tossed and lost, causing a roar of excitement from those watching. Barlden looked as if he wanted to toss Mat out - it was getting late, and sunset couldn't be far off - but the man hesitated when he saw Mat pull out another handful of gold coins. Greed nibbled every man, and strict "rules"

kəd bi bɛn ɪf ɑpɝtunəɾi wɔk pæst ən wɪŋk sədʒɛstɪvli ɪnʌf.

could be bent if opportunity walked past and winked suggestively enough.

mæt tɔst əɡɛn, ən lɔst. mɔɹ ɹɔɹz. ðə meɪɝ foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz.

Mat tossed again, and lost. More roars. The mayor folded his arms.

mæt ɹitʃt ɪndə hɪz paʊtʃ ən faʊnd nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ɛɹ. ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ɪm lʊkt kɹɛstfɔlən, ən wʌn kɔl fəɹ ə ɹaʊn ə dʒɹɪŋks tə "hɛlp ðə pʊɹ jʌŋ lɔɹd fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪz lʌk."

Mat reached into his pouch and found nothing but air. The men around him looked crestfallen, and one called for a round of drinks to "help the poor young lord forget about his luck."

nɑt blʌɾi laɪkli, mæt θɔt, kʌvɝɪŋ ə smaɪl. hi stʊɾ ʌp, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hænz. "aɪ si ɪts ɡɛɾɪŋ leɪt," hi sɛd tə ðə ɹum.

Not bloody likely, Mat thought, covering a smile. He stood up, raising his hands. "I see it's getting late," he said to the room.

"tu leɪt," bɑɹldən ɪntɝdʒɛktɪd, pʊʃɪŋ pæst ə fju smɛli ɡoʊðɝdz wɪð fɝ-kɑlɝd kloʊks.

"Too late," Barlden interjected, pushing past a few smelly goatherds with fur-collared cloaks.

"ju ʃəd bi ɡoʊɪŋ, aʊtləndɝ. doʊn bi θɪŋkɪŋ əl meɪk ðiz mɛn ɡɪv bæk wʌt jə lɔs tə ðɛm fɛɹli, iðɝ."

"You should be going, outlander. Don't be thinking I'll make these men give back what you lost to them fairly, either."

"aɪ wʊdn dʒɹim ʌv ɪt," mæt sɛd, slɝɪŋ ɪz wɝdz dʒʌst ə tæd. "hɑɹnən ən dɛlɑɹn!" hi bɛloʊd. "bɹɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃɛst!"

"I wouldn't dream of it," Mat said, slurring his words just a tad. "Harnan and Delarn!" he bellowed. "Bring in the chest!"

ðə tu soʊlʒɝz fɹəm aʊtsaɪd hɝiɾ ɪn ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, bɛɹɪŋ ðə smɔl wʊɾən tʃɛs fɹəm ðə pækhɔɹs. ðə tævɝn ɡɹu saɪlən əz ðə soʊlʒɝ kæɹiɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ tə ðə teɪbəl ən sɛɾ ɪt daʊn. mæt fɪʃt aʊt ðə ki, wɑbəlɪŋ slaɪtli, ðən ənlɑk ðə lɪɾ ən ɹɪvil ðə kɑntɛns.

The two soldiers from outside hurried in a moment later, bearing the small wooden chest from the packhorse. The tavern grew silent as the soldier carried it over to the table and set it down. Mat fished out the key, wobbling slightly, then unlocked the lid and revealed the contents.

ɡoʊld. ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪt. pɹæktəkli ɔl i hæd lɛft ə hɪz pɝsənəl kɔɪn. "ðɛɹz taɪm fəɹ wʌn mɔɹ θɹoʊ," mæt sɛd tə ə stʌn ɹum. "ɛni teɪkɝz?"

Gold. A lot of it. Practically all he had left of his personal coin. "There's time for one more throw," Mat said to a stunned room. "Any takers?"

mɛn bɪɡæn tə tɔs daʊn kɔɪnz əntɪl ðə paɪl kənteɪn moʊst ʌv wʌt mæt hæd lɔst. ɪt wɑznt nɪɹli ɪnʌf tə mætʃ wʌt wɑz ɪn ɪz tʃɛst. hi lʊkt ɪɾ oʊvɝ, tæpɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "ðæts nɑt gɑnə bi ɪnʌf, fɹɛnz. əl teɪk ə bæd bɛt, bʌɾ ɪf aɪv oʊnli ɡɑt wʌn mɔɹ θɹoʊ tənaɪt, aɪ wɑn ə tʃæns ʌv wɔkɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ wɪð sʌmθɪŋ."

Men began to toss down coins until the pile contained most of what Mat had lost. It wasn't nearly enough to match what was in his chest. He looked it over, tapping his chin. "That's not going to be enough, friends. I'll take a bad bet, but if I've only got one more throw tonight, I want a chance of walking out of here with something."

"ɪts ɔl wiv ɡɑt," wʌn ə ðə mɛn sɛd, əmɪɾ ə fju kɔlz fəɹ mæt tə ɡoʊ əhɛɾ ən tɔs ɛniweɪ.

"It's all we've got," one of the men said, amid a few calls for Mat to go ahead and toss anyway.

mæt saɪd, ðən kloʊz ðə lɪd tə ðə tʃɛst. "noʊ," hi sɛd. ivən bɑɹldən wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ wɪð ə ɡlim ɪn ɪz aɪz. "ənlɛs." mæt pɔzd. "aɪ keɪm hɪɹ fəɹ səplaɪz. aɪ ɡɛs aɪd teɪk bɑɹɾɝ. jə kən kip ðə kɔɪnz jə wʌn, bʌɾ əl bɛt ðɪs tʃɛs fəɹ səplaɪz. fudstʌfs fəɹ maɪ mɛn, ə fju kæsks ʌv eɪl.

Mat sighed, then closed the lid to the chest. "No," he said. Even Barlden was watching with a gleam in his eyes. "Unless." Mat paused. "I came here for supplies. I guess I'd take barter. You can keep the coins you won, but I'll bet this chest for supplies. Foodstuffs for my men, a few casks of ale.

ə kɑɹt tə kæɹi ɪɾ ɑn."

A cart to carry it on."

"ðɛɹ ɪzən ɪnʌf taɪm." bɑɹldən ɡlænst ət ðə dɑɹkənɪŋ wɪndoʊz.

"There isn't enough time." Barlden glanced at the darkening windows.

"ʃʊɹli ðəɹ ɪz," mæt sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. "aɪl liv æftɝ ðɪs tɔs. juv maɪ wɝɾ ɑn ɪt."

"Surely there is," Mat said, leaning forward. "I'll leave after this toss. You have my word on it."

"wi doʊn bɛn ɹulz hɪɹ," ðə meɪɝ sɛd. "ðə pɹaɪs ɪz tu haɪ."

"We don't bend rules here," the mayor said. "The price is too high."

mæt ɪkspɛktəd kɔlz fɹəm ðə bɛɾɪŋ mɛn, tʃælənʒɪŋ ðə meɪɝ, bɛɡɪŋ ɪm tə meɪk ən ɪksɛpʃən. bʌt ðəɹ wɝ nʌn. mæt fɛlt ə sʌɾən spaɪk ə fɪɹ. æftɝ ɔl ə ðət luzɪŋ . . . ɪf ðeɪ kɪkt ɪm aʊɾ ɛniweɪ. . . .

Mat expected calls from the betting men, challenging the mayor, begging him to make an exception. But there were none. Mat felt a sudden spike of fear. After all of that losing . . . if they kicked him out anyway. . . .

dɛspɹɪt, hi pʊld oʊpən ðə tɑp ə ðə tʃɛst əɡɛn, ɹɪvilɪŋ ðə ɡoʊl kɔɪnz ɪnsaɪd.

Desperate, he pulled open the top of the chest again, revealing the gold coins inside.

"aɪl ɡɪv jə ði eɪl," ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd sʌɾənli. "æn mɑɹdʒɹi, juv ɡɑɾ ə wæɡən ən tim.

"I'll give you the ale," the innkeeper said suddenly. "And Mardry, you've got a wagon and team.

ɪts oʊnli ə stʃɹit daʊn."

It's only a street down."

"jɛs," sɛd mɑɹdʒɹi, ə blʌf-feɪs mæn wɪð ʃɔɹt dɑɹk hɛɹ. "aɪl bɛt ðæt."

"Yes," said Mardry, a bluff-faced man with short dark hair. "I'll bet that."

mɛn bɪɡæn tə kɔl ðət ðeɪ kəɾ ɔfɝ fud - ɡɹeɪn fɹəm ðɛɹ pæntʃɹiz, pəteɪɾoʊz fɹəm ðɛɹ sɛlɝz. mæt lʊk tə ðə meɪɝ. "ðɛɹz stɪl ɡɑt tə bi wʌt, hæf ən aʊɝ əntɪl naɪtfɔl? waɪ doʊnt wi si wʌt ðeɪ kən ɡæðɝ? ðə vɪlədʒ stɔɹ kən əv ə pis ə ðɪs tu, ɪf aɪ luz. əl bɛt jə kəd juz ði ɛkstʃɹə kɔɪn, wʌt wɪð ðə wɪntɝ wi hæd."

Men began to call that they could offer food - grain from their pantries, potatoes from their cellars. Mat looked to the mayor. "There's still got to be what, half an hour until nightfall? Why don't we see what they can gather? The village store can have a piece of this too, if I lose. I'll bet you could use the extra coin, what with the winter we had."

bɑɹldən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd, stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɛst ə kɔɪnz. mɛn wupt ən ɹæn əbaʊt, fɛtʃɪŋ ðə wæɡən, ɹoʊlɪŋ aʊt ði eɪl. mɔɹ ðən ə fju ɡæləpt ɔf fəɹ ðɛɹ hoʊmz əɹ ðə vɪlədʒ stɔɹ. mæt wɑtʃt əm ɡoʊ, weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə kwɪkli ɛmptiɪŋ tævɝn ɹum.

Barlden hesitated, then nodded, still watching the chest of coins. Men whooped and ran about, fetching the wagon, rolling out the ale. More than a few galloped off for their homes or the village store. Mat watched them go, waiting in the quickly emptying tavern room.

"aɪ si wʌt jəɹ duɪŋ," ðə meɪɝ sɛd tə mæt. hi dɪdn sim tə bi ɪn ə ɹʌʃ tə ɡæðɝ ɛniθɪŋ.

"I see what you're doing," the mayor said to Mat. He didn't seem to be in a rush to gather anything.

mæt tɝn təwɔɹd hɪm, kwɛstʃənɪŋli.

Mat turned toward him, questioningly.

"aɪ woʊn əv jə tʃiɾɪŋ əs wɪð ə mɪɹəkəl wɪn ət ði ɛn ə ði ivnɪŋ." bɑɹldən foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz. "jul juz maɪ daɪs. ən jəl muv naɪs ən sloʊ əz jə tɔs. aɪ noʊ jə lɔs mɛni ɡeɪmz hɪɹ əz ðə mɛn ɹipɔɹt, bʌɾ aɪ səspɛk ðəɾ ɪf wi sɝtʃ ju, wɪl faɪn ə kʌpəl ə sɛts ə daɪs hɪɾən ɑn jəɹ pɝsən."

"I won't have you cheating us with a miracle win at the end of the evening." Barlden folded his arms. "You'll use my dice. And you'll move nice and slow as you toss. I know you lost many games here as the men report, but I suspect that if we search you, we'll find a couple of sets of dice hidden on your person."

"jɔɹ wɛlkəm tə ɡɪmi ə sɝtʃ," mæt sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz tə ðə saɪd.

"You're welcome to give me a search," Mat said, raising his arms to the side.

bɑɹldən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ju wɪl əv θɹoʊn əm əweɪ, ʌv kɔɹs," hi faɪnəli sɛd. "ɪts ə faɪn skim, dʒɹɛsɪŋ laɪk ə lɔɹd, loʊɾɪŋ daɪs soʊ ðeɪ meɪk jə luz ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wɪn. nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə mæn boʊld ɪnʌf tə θɹoʊ əweɪ ɡoʊld laɪk ðəɾ ɑn feɪk daɪs."

Barlden hesitated. "You will have thrown them away, of course," he finally said. "It's a fine scheme, dressing like a lord, loading dice so they make you lose instead of win. Never heard of a man bold enough to throw away gold like that on fake dice."

"ɪf jəɹ soʊ sɝɾən ðəɾ aɪm tʃiɾɪŋ," mæt sɛd, "ðɛn waɪ ɡoʊ θɹu wɪð ðɪs?"

"If you're so certain that I'm cheating," Mat said, "then why go through with this?"

"bɪkɔz aɪ noʊ haʊ tə stɑp ju," ðə meɪɝ ɹɪplaɪd. "laɪk aɪ sɛd, jəl juz maɪ daɪs ɑn ðɪs θɹoʊ." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən smaɪld, ɡɹæbɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə daɪs ɔf ðə teɪbəl ðət mæt hæd bɪn juzɪŋ. hi tɔs ðɛm. ðeɪ keɪm ʌp ə wʌn ən ə tu. hi tɔst əm əɡɛn, ən ɡɑt ðə seɪm ɹɪzʌlt.

"Because I know how to stop you," the mayor replied. "Like I said, you'll use my dice on this throw." He hesitated, then smiled, grabbing a pair of dice off the table that Mat had been using. He tossed them. They came up a one and a two. He tossed them again, and got the same result.

"bɛɾɝ jɛt." ðə meɪɝ smaɪl dipli. "jul juz ðiz. ɪn fækt . . . əl meɪk ðə θɹoʊ fəɹ ju."

"Better yet." The mayor smiled deeply. "You'll use these. In fact . . . I'll make the throw for you."

bɑɹldənz feɪs ɪn ðə dɪm laɪt tʊk ɑn ə dɪsaɪɾədli sɪnɪstɝ kæst.

Barlden's face in the dim light took on a decidedly sinister cast.

mæt fɛlt ə stæb ə pænɪk.

Mat felt a stab of panic.

tælmɑnz tʊk ɪz ɑɹm. "ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt," hi sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd ɡoʊ."

Talmanes took his arm. "All right, Mat," he said. "I think we should go."

mæt hɛld ʌp ə hænd. wəɾ ɪz lʌk wɝk ɪf sʌmwʌn ɛls θɹu? səmtaɪmz ɪt wɝk tə pɹɪvɛn ɪm fɹəm biɪŋ wundəɾ ɪn kɑmbæt. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ə ðæt. wɑzn hi?

Mat held up a hand. Would his luck work if someone else threw? Sometimes it worked to prevent him from being wounded in combat. He was sure of that. Wasn't he?

"ɡoʊ əhɛd," hi sɛd tə bɑɹldən.

"Go ahead," he said to Barlden.

ðə mæn lʊkt ʃɑkt.

The man looked shocked.

"ju kən meɪk ðə θɹoʊ," mæt sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪt kaʊns ðə seɪm əz ɪf aɪd tɔst. ə wɪnɪŋ hænd, ən aɪ wɔk əweɪ wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ə luzɪŋ hænd, ən əl bi ɑn maɪ weɪ wɪð maɪ hæɾ ən maɪ hɔɹs, ən jə kən kip ðə blʌɾi tʃɛst. əɡɹid?"

"You can make the throw," Mat said. "But it counts the same as if I'd tossed. A winning hand, and I walk away with everything. A losing hand, and I'll be on my way with my hat and my horse, and you can keep the bloody chest. Agreed?"

"əɡɹid."

"Agreed."

mæt stʌk aʊɾ ɪz hæn fəɹ ə ʃeɪk, bʌt ðə meɪɝ tɝn əweɪ, hoʊldɪŋ ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hænd. "noʊ,"

Mat stuck out his hand for a shake, but the mayor turned away, holding the dice in his hand. "No,"

hi sɛd. "jul ɡɛt noʊ tʃæns tə swɑp ðiz daɪs, tʃɹævəlɝ. lɛts dʒʌst ɡoʊ aʊt fɹʌn ən weɪt. ən jə kip jəɹ dɪstəns."

he said. "You'll get no chance to swap these dice, traveler. Let's just go out front and wait. And you keep your distance."

ðeɪ dɪɾ əz i sɛd, livɪŋ ðə mʌɡi, eɪl-soʊk stɛntʃ ə ðə tævɝn fəɹ ðə klɪɹ stʃɹiɾ aʊtsaɪd.

They did as he said, leaving the muggy, ale-soaked stench of the tavern for the clear street outside.

mæts soʊlʒɝz bɹɔt ðə tʃɛst. bɑɹldən dɪmændəd ðət ðə tʃɛst ɹɪmeɪn oʊpən soʊ ðəɾ ɪt kʊdn bi swɪtʃt. wʌn ə hɪz θʌɡz poʊkt ɝaʊn ɪnsaɪɾ ɪt, baɪɾɪŋ ðə kɔɪnz, meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən ðəɾ ɪt ɹɪli wɑz fʊl ən ðət ðə kɔɪnz wɝ əθɛntɪk. mæt weɪɾəd, linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə dɔɹ əz ə wæɡən ɹoʊld ʌp, ən mɛn fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə tævɝn bɪɡæn ɹoʊlɪŋ kæsks ʌv eɪl ɑntu ɪts bɛd.

Mat's soldiers brought the chest. Barlden demanded that the chest remain open so that it couldn't be switched. One of his thugs poked around inside it, biting the coins, making certain that it really was full and that the coins were authentic. Mat waited, leaning against the door as a wagon rolled up, and men from inside the tavern began rolling casks of ale onto its bed.

ðə sʌn wɑz bɛɹli ə heɪz ə laɪɾ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən, bɪhaɪn ðoʊz blæstəd klaʊdz. əz mæt weɪɾəd, hi sɔ ðə meɪɝ ɡɹoʊ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ æŋkʃəs. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz, ðə mæn wɑz ə stɪkəlɝ fəɹ ɪz ɹulz! wɛl, mæt wəd ʃoʊ hɪm, ən ɔl ə ðɛm. hid ʃoʊ ðɛm. . . .

The sun was barely a haze of light on the horizon, behind those blasted clouds. As Mat waited, he saw the mayor grow more and more anxious. Blood and bloody ashes, the man was a stickler for his rules! Well, Mat would show him, and all of them. He'd show them. . . .

ʃoʊ ðɛm wʌt? ðəɾ i kʊdn bi biɾən? wʌd ðət pɹuv? əz mæt weɪɾəd, ðə kɑɹt paɪl haɪɝ ən haɪɝ wɪð fudstʌfs, ən i bɪɡæn tə fil ə stʃɹeɪnʒ sɛns ʌv ɡɪlt.

Show them what? That he couldn't be beaten? What did that prove? As Mat waited, the cart piled higher and higher with foodstuffs, and he began to feel a strange sense of guilt.

aɪm nɑt duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ, hi θɔt. aɪv ɡɑt tə fid maɪ mɛn, doʊn aɪ? ðiz mɛn ɑɹ bɛɾɪŋ fɛɹ, ən aɪm bɛɾɪŋ fɛɹ. noʊ loʊɾəd daɪs. noʊ tʃiɾɪŋ.

I'm not doing anything wrong, he thought. I've got to feed my men, don't I? These men are betting fair, and I'm betting fair. No loaded dice. No cheating.

ɪksɛpt ɪz lʌk. wɛl, hɪz lʌk wɑz ɪz oʊn - dʒʌst əz ɛvɹi mænz lʌk wɑz ɪz oʊn. səm mɛn wɝ bɔɹn wɪð ə tælən fəɹ mjuzɪk, ən ðeɪ bɪkeɪm bɑɹdz ən ɡlimən. hu bɪɡɹʌdʒd əm ɝnɪŋ kɔɪn wɪð wʌt ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ɡeɪv ðɛm? mæt hæd lʌk, ən soʊ hi juzd ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð ðæt.

Except his luck. Well, his luck was his own - just as every man's luck was his own. Some men were born with a talent for music, and they became bards and gleemen. Who begrudged them earning coin with what the Creator gave them? Mat had luck, and so he used it. There was nothing wrong with that.

stɪl, əz ðə mɛn keɪm bæk ɪndə ði ɪn, hi stɑɹɾəd tə si wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðət tælmɑnz hæd noʊɾəst.

Still, as the men came back into the inn, he started to see what it was that Talmanes had noticed.

ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛdʒ ə dɛspɝeɪʃən tə ðiz mɛn. hæd ðeɪ bɪn tu iɡɝ tə ɡæmbəl? hæd ðeɪ bɪn fulhɑɹɾi wɪð ðɛɹ bɛɾɪŋ? wʌt wɑz ðət lʊk ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, ə lʊk ðət mæt hæd mɪsteɪkən fəɹ wɪɹinəs? hæd ðeɪ bɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ tə sɛləbɹeɪt ði ɛn ə ðə deɪ, əɹ hæd ðeɪ bɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ tə bænɪʃ ðət hɔntəd kæst ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz?

There was an edge of desperation to these men. Had they been too eager to gamble? Had they been foolhardy with their betting? What was that look in their eyes, a look that Mat had mistaken for weariness? Had they been drinking to celebrate the end of the day, or had they been drinking to banish that haunted cast in their eyes?

"meɪbi jə wɝ ɹaɪt," mæt sɛd tə tælmɑnz, hu wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðə sʌn wɪð ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ æŋzaɪəɾi əz ðə meɪɝ. ɪts læs laɪt wɑz dʌstɪŋ ðə tɑps ə ðə pik hoʊmz, kʌlɝɪŋ ðə tæn taɪl ə dipɝ ɔɹənʒ. ðə sʌnsɛt wɑz ə bleɪz bɪhaɪn ðə klaʊdz.

"Maybe you were right," Mat said to Talmanes, who was watching the sun with almost as much anxiety as the mayor. Its last light was dusting the tops of the peaked homes, coloring the tan tile a deeper orange. The sunset was a blaze behind the clouds.

"wi kən ɡoʊ, ðɛn?" tælmɑnz æskt.

"We can go, then?" Talmanes asked.

"noʊ," mæt sɛd. "wɝ steɪɪŋ."

"No," Mat said. "We're staying."

ən ðə daɪs stɑpt ɹætlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd. ɪt wɑz soʊ sʌɾən, ðə saɪləns soʊ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd, ðəɾ i fɹoʊz. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm θɪŋk hid meɪd ðə ɹɔŋ dɪsɪʒən.

And the dice stopped rattling in his head. It was so sudden, the silence so unexpected, that he froze. It was enough to make him think he'd made the wrong decision.

"bɝn mi, wɝ steɪɪŋ," hi ɹɪpiɾɪd. "aɪv nɛvɝ bæk daʊn fɹəm ə bɛt bɪfɔɹ, ən aɪ doʊn plæn tə naʊ."

"Burn me, we're staying," he repeated. "I've never backed down from a bet before, and I don't plan to now."

ə ɡɹup ə ɹaɪɾɝz ɹɪtɝnd, bɛɹɪŋ sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ɪt wɑz əmeɪzɪŋ wʌɾ ə lɪɾəl kɔɪn kəd də fəɹ moʊɾəveɪʃən. əz mɔɹ ɹaɪɾɝz ɝaɪvd, ə jʌŋ bɔɪ keɪm tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹoʊd.

A group of riders returned, bearing sacks of grain on their horses. It was amazing what a little coin could do for motivation. As more riders arrived, a young boy came trotting up the road.

"meɪɝ," hi sɛd, tʌɡɪŋ ɑn bɑɹldənz pɝpəl vɛst. ðət vɛs bɔɹ ə kɹɪskɹɔs ə pætʃt ɹɪps əkɹɔs ðə fɹʌnt. "mʌðɝ sɛz ðət ði aʊtləndɝ wɪmən ɑɹən dʌn beɪðɪŋ. ʃiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hɝi ðɛm, bʌt. . . ."

"Mayor," he said, tugging on Barlden's purple vest. That vest bore a crisscross of patched rips across the front. "Mother says that the outlander women aren't done bathing. She's trying to hurry them, but. . . ."

ðə meɪɝ tɛnst. hi ɡlænst ət mæt æŋɡɹəli.

The mayor tensed. He glanced at Mat angrily.

mæt snɔɹɾɪd. "doʊn θɪŋk aɪ kən də ɛniθɪŋ tə hɝi ðət lɑt," hi sɛd. "ɪf aɪ wɝ tə ɡoʊ ɹʌʃ ðɛm, ðeɪd laɪkli dɪɡ ɪn laɪk mjulz ən teɪk twaɪs əz lɔŋ. lɛt sʌmwʌn ɛls blʌɾi hæv ə tɝn dilɪŋ wɪð ðɛm."

Mat snorted. "Don't think I can do anything to hurry that lot," he said. "If I were to go rush them, they'd likely dig in like mules and take twice as long. Let someone else bloody have a turn dealing with them."

tælmɑnz kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə lɛŋθənɪŋ ʃædoʊz əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd. "bɝn mi," hi mʌɾɝd. "ɪf ðoʊz ɡoʊsts stɑɹɾ əpɪɹɪŋ əɡɛn, mæt. . . ."

Talmanes kept glancing at the lengthening shadows along the road. "Burn me," he muttered. "If those ghosts start appearing again, Mat. . . ."

"ðɪs ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls," mæt sɛɾ əz ðə nukʌmɝz θɹu ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪn ɑntu ðə wæɡən. "ɪt filz dɪfɹənt."

"This is something else," Mat said as the newcomers threw their grain onto the wagon. "It feels different."

ðə wæɡən wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi loʊɾəd haɪ wɪð fudstʌfs; ə ɡʊd hɔl tə hæv pɝtʃəs fɹəm ə vɪlədʒ ðɪs saɪz. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst wʌt ðə bænd niɾəd, ɪnʌf tə nʌdʒ əm əlɔŋ, kip əm fɛɾ əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə nɛks taʊn. ðət fud wɑznt wɝθ ðə ɡoʊld ɪn ðə kɔfɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz əbaʊɾ ikwəl tə wʌt hid lɔs dɪsɪŋ ɪnsaɪd, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wɪð ðə wæɡən ən hɔɹsəz θɹoʊn ɪn. ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊd dʒɹæft ænəməlz, stɝɾi, wɛl kɛɹd fəɹ fɹəm ðə lʊk ə koʊɾ ən huf.

The wagon was already loaded high with foodstuffs; a good haul to have purchased from a village this size. It was just what the Band needed, enough to nudge them along, keep them fed until they reached the next town. That food wasn't worth the gold in the coffer, of course, but it was about equal to what he'd lost dicing inside, particularly with the wagon and horses thrown in. They were good draft animals, sturdy, well cared for from the look of coat and hoof.

mæt oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə seɪ ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz i noʊɾəst ðət ðə meɪɝ wɑz tɔkɪŋ kwaɪətli wɪð ə ɡɹup ə mɛn. ðəɹ wɝ sɪks ə ðɛm, ðɛɹ vɛsts dʒɹæb ən ɹæɡəd, ðɛɹ blæk hɛɹ ənkɛmpt. wʌn wɑz dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ təwɔɹd mæt ən hoʊldɪŋ wʌt lʊk tə bi ə ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ ɪn ɪz hænd.

Mat opened his mouth to say it was enough, then hesitated as he noticed that the mayor was talking quietly with a group of men. There were six of them, their vests drab and ragged, their black hair unkempt. One was gesturing toward Mat and holding what looked to be a sheet of paper in his hand.

bɑɹldən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, bʌt ðə mæn wɪð ðə peɪpɝ dʒɛstʃɝd mɔɹ ɪnsɪstənli.

Barlden shook his head, but the man with the paper gestured more insistently.

"hɪɹ naʊ," mæt sɛd sɔfli. "wʌts ðɪs?"

"Here now," Mat said softly. "What's this?"

"mæt, ðə sʌn . . ." tælmɑnz sɛd.

"Mat, the sun . . ." Talmanes said.

ðə meɪɝ pɔɪntəd ʃɑɹpli, ən ðə ɹæɡəd mɛn saɪɾəld əweɪ. ðə mɛn u hæd bɹɔt ðə fud wɝ kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə dɪmɪŋ stʃɹit, kipɪŋ tə ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɪt. moʊst wɝ lʊkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən.

The mayor pointed sharply, and the ragged men sidled away. The men who had brought the food were crowding around the dimming street, keeping to the center of it. Most were looking toward the horizon.

"meɪɝ," mæt kɔld. "ðæts ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf. meɪk ðə θɹoʊ!"

"Mayor," Mat called. "That's good enough. Make the throw!"

bɑɹldən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət hɪm, ðən lʊk daʊn ət ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hæn ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf hid fɝɡɑɾən ðɛm. ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ɪm nɑɾəd æŋkʃəsli, ən soʊ hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn ɪn ə fɪst, ɹætlɪŋ ðə daɪs. ðə meɪɝ lʊkt əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit tə mit mæts aɪz, ðən θɹu ðə daɪs ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪtwin ðɛm. ðeɪ sim tu laʊd, ə taɪni ɹætlɪŋ θʌndɝstɔɹm, laɪk boʊnz kɹækɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ.

Barlden hesitated, glancing at him, then looked down at the dice in his hand almost as if he'd forgotten them. The men around him nodded anxiously, and so he raised his hand in a fist, rattling the dice. The mayor looked across the street to meet Mat's eyes, then threw the dice onto the ground between them. They seemed too loud, a tiny rattling thunderstorm, like bones cracking against one another.

mæt hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ. ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ waɪl sɪns hid hæd ɹizən tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ə tɔs ə ðə daɪs. hi lin daʊn, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə waɪt kjubz tʌmbəl əɡɛns ðə dɝt. haʊ wəɾ ɪz lʌk ɹiæk tə sʌmwʌn ɛls θɹoʊɪŋ?

Mat held his breath. It had been a long while since he'd had reason to worry about a toss of the dice. He leaned down, watching the white cubes tumble against the dirt. How would his luck react to someone else throwing?

ðə daɪs keɪm tə ə stɑp. ə pɛɹ ə fɔɹz. ən aʊtʃɹaɪt wɪnɪŋ θɹoʊ. mæt ɹilist ə lɔŋ, ɹɪliv bɹɛθ, ðoʊ hi fɛlt ə tʃɹɪkəl ə swɛt daʊn ɪz tɛmpəl.

The dice came to a stop. A pair of fours. An outright winning throw. Mat released a long, relieved breath, though he felt a trickle of sweat down his temple.

"mæt . . ." tælmɑnz sɛd sɔfli, meɪkɪŋ ɪm lʊk ʌp. ðə mɛn stændɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd dɪdn lʊk soʊ plizd. sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm tʃɪɹɾ ɪn ɪksaɪtmən əntɪl ðɛɹ fɹɛnz ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ ə wɪnɪŋ θɹoʊ fɹəm ðə meɪɝ mɛn ðət mæt wəd teɪk ðə pɹaɪz. ðə kɹaʊd ɡɹu tɛns. mæt mɛt bɑɹldənz aɪz.

"Mat . . ." Talmanes said softly, making him look up. The men standing on the road didn't look so pleased. Several of them cheered in excitement until their friends explained that a winning throw from the mayor meant that Mat would take the prize. The crowd grew tense. Mat met Barlden's eyes.

"ɡoʊ," ðə bɝli mæn sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ɪn dɪsɡʌs təwɔɹd mæt ən tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. "teɪk jəɹ spɔɪlz ən liv ðɪs pleɪs. nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn."

"Go," the burly man said, gesturing in disgust toward Mat and turning away. "Take your spoils and leave this place. Never return."

"wɛl," mæt sɛd, ɹɪlæksɪŋ. "θæŋk jə kaɪnli fəɹ ðə ɡeɪm, ðɛn. wi - "

"Well," Mat said, relaxing. "Thank you kindly for the game, then. We - "

"ɡoʊ!" ðə meɪɝ bɛloʊd. hi lʊkt ət ðə læst slɪvɝz ə sʌnlaɪɾ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən, ðən kɝst ən bɪɡæn weɪvɪŋ fəɹ ðə mɛn tə ɛntɝ ðə tɪpsi ɡɛldɪŋ. səm lɪŋɡɝd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət mæt wɪð ʃɑk əɹ hɑstɪləɾi, bʌt ðə meɪɝz ɝdʒɪŋz sun bʊliɾ əm ɪndə ðə loʊ-ɹuft ɪn. hi pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌɾ ən lɛf mæt, tælmɑnz ən ðə tu soʊlʒɝz stændɪŋ əloʊn ɑn ðə stʃɹit.

"GO!" the mayor bellowed. He looked at the last slivers of sunlight on the horizon, then cursed and began waving for the men to enter The Tipsy Gelding. Some lingered, glancing at Mat with shock or hostility, but the mayor's urgings soon bullied them into the low-roofed inn. He pulled the door shut and left Mat, Talmanes and the two soldiers standing alone on the street.

ɪt sʌɾənli simd ɪɹəli kwaɪət. ðəɹ wɑzn ə vɪlɪdʒɝ ɑn ðə stʃɹit. ʃʊdn ðəɹ bi səm nɔɪz fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə tævɝn, ət list? səm klɪŋkɪŋ ə mʌɡz, səm ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ əbaʊt ðə lɔst weɪdʒɝ?

It suddenly seemed eerily quiet. There wasn't a villager on the street. Shouldn't there be some noise from inside the tavern, at least? Some clinking of mugs, some grumbling about the lost wager?

"wɛl," mæt sɛd, vɔɪs ɛkoʊɪŋ əɡɛnst saɪlən haʊsfɹʌns, "aɪ ɡɛs ðæts ðæt." hi wɔkt oʊvɝ tə pɪps, kɑmɪŋ ðə hɔɹs, hu hæd bɪɡʌn tə ʃʌfəl nɝvəsli. "naʊ, si, aɪ toʊl ju, tælmɑnz.

"Well," Mat said, voice echoing against silent housefronts, "I guess that's that." He walked over to Pips, calming the horse, who had begun to shuffle nervously. "Now, see, I told you, Talmanes.

nʌθɪŋ tə bi wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ əɾ ɔl."

Nothing to be worried about at all."

ən ðæts wən ðə skɹimɪŋ bɪɡæn.

And that's when the screaming began.

tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt

CHAPTER 28

naɪɾ ɪn hɪndɝstæp "bɝn ju, mæt!" tælmɑnz sɛd, jæŋkɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd fɹi fɹəm ðə ɡʌɾ ʌv ə twɪtʃɪŋ vɪlɪdʒɝ.

Night in Hinderstap "Burn you, Mat!" Talmanes said, yanking his sword free from the gut of a twitching villager.

tælmɑnz ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ swɔɹ. "bɝn jə twaɪs oʊvɝ ən wʌns əɡɛn!"

Talmanes almost never swore. "Burn you twice over and once again!"

"mi? " mæt snæpt, spɪnɪŋ, hɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ flæʃɪŋ əz i nitli hæmstʃɹəŋ tu mɛn ɪn bɹaɪt ɡɹin vɛsts. ðeɪ fɛl tə ðə pækt ɝθən stʃɹit, aɪz waɪd wɪð ɹeɪdʒ əz ðeɪ spʌɾɝd ən ɡɹaʊld.

"Me? " Mat snapped, spinning, his ashandarei flashing as he neatly hamstrung two men in bright green vests. They fell to the packed earthen street, eyes wide with rage as they sputtered and growled.

"mi? aɪm nɑt ðə wʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ju, tælmɑnz. bleɪm ðɛm!"

"Me? I'm not the one trying to kill you, Talmanes. Blame them!"

tælmɑnz mænədʒ tə pʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl. "ðeɪ toʊld əs tə liv!"

Talmanes managed to pull himself into his saddle. "They told us to leave!"

"jɛs," mæt sɛd, ɡɹæbɪŋ pɪps' ɹeɪnz ən pʊlɪŋ ðə hɔɹs əweɪ fɹəm ðə tɪpsi ɡɛldɪŋ. "ænd naʊ ðəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ʌs. aɪ kæn ɹaɪtli bi bleɪm fəɹ ðɛɹ ənsoʊtʃəbəl bɪheɪvjɝ!" haʊlz, skɹimz, ən jɛlz ɹoʊz fɹəm ɔl əkɹɔs ðə vɪlədʒ. səm wɝ æŋɡɹi, səm wɝ tɛɹəfaɪd, ʌðɝz wɝ æɡənaɪzd.

"Yes," Mat said, grabbing Pips' reins and pulling the horse away from The Tipsy Gelding. "And now they're trying to kill us. I can't rightly be blamed for their unsociable behavior!" Howls, screams, and yells rose from all across the village. Some were angry, some were terrified, others were agonized.

mɔɹ ən mɔɹ mɛn paɪld aʊɾ ə ðə tævɝn, itʃ wʌn ɡɹʌntɪŋ ən jɛlɪŋ, itʃ wʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ ɪz bɛs tə kɪl ɛvɹi pɝsən ɝaʊn hɪm. səm ə ðɛm keɪm fəɹ mæt, tælmɑnz əɹ mæts ɹɛdʒɹmz. bʌt mɛni dʒʌst ətæk ðɛɹ kəmpænjənz, hænz ɹɪpɪŋ ət skɪn, neɪlz tɛɹɪŋ ɡaʊudʒɪz ɪn feɪsəz. ðeɪ fɔt wɪð ə pɹaɪməl læk ə skɪl, ən oʊnli ə fju θɔt tə pɪk ʌp ɹɑks, mʌɡz əɹ lɛŋθs ʌv wʊɾ əz wɛpənz.

More and more men piled out of the tavern, each one grunting and yelling, each one trying his best to kill every person around him. Some of them came for Mat, Talmanes or Mat's Redarms. But many just attacked their companions, hands ripping at skin, nails tearing gouges in faces. They fought with a primal lack of skill, and only a few thought to pick up rocks, mugs or lengths of wood as weapons.

ðɪs wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ə sɪmpəl bɑɹ faɪt. ðiz mɛn wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl itʃ ʌðɝ. ɔlɹɛɾi ðəɹ wɝ ə hæf-dʌzən kɔɹpsəz əɹ nɪɹ-kɔɹpsəz ɑn ðə stʃɹit, ən fɹəm wʌt mæt kəd si ʌv ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ði ɪn, ðə faɪɾɪŋ wɑz ikwəli bɹuɾəl ɪnsaɪd.

This was far more than a simple bar fight. These men were trying to kill each other. Already there were a half-dozen corpses or near-corpses on the street, and from what Mat could see of the inside of the inn, the fighting was equally brutal inside.

mæt tʃɹaɪd tə ɛdʒ kloʊsɝ tə ðə wæɡən wɪð ɪts loʊɾ ə fud, pɪps klɑpɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd hɪm. hɪz tʃɛst ʌv ɡoʊl stɪl leɪ ɑn ðə stʃɹit. ðə faɪɾɪŋ mɛn ɪɡnɔɹd boʊθ fuɾ ən kɔɪn, kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝ.

Mat tried to edge closer to the wagon with its load of food, Pips clopping alongside him. His chest of gold still lay on the street. The fighting men ignored both food and coin, concentrating on one another.

tælmɑnz, əz wɛl əz hɑɹnən ən dɛlɑɹn - hɪz tu soʊlʒɝz - bækt əweɪ wɪð hɪm, nɝvəsli pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn maʊns. ə ɡɹup ə ɹeɪvɪŋ mɛn sun dɪsɛndəɾ ɑn ðə tu vɪlɪdʒɝz mæt hæd hæmstʃɹəŋ, biɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz əɡɛns ðə ɡɹaʊn oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ əntɪl ðeɪ stɑp muvɪŋ. ðən ðə pæk lʊkt ʌp ət mæt ən ɪz mɛn, blʌdlʌs klaʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz. ɪt wɑz ən ɪŋkɔŋɹuəs ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ðə klin feɪsəz ə mɛn ɪn nit vɛsts ən koʊm hɛɹ.

Talmanes, as well as Harnan and Delarn - his two soldiers - backed away with him, nervously pulling their own mounts. A group of raving men soon descended on the two villagers Mat had hamstrung, beating their heads against the ground over and over until they stopped moving. Then the pack looked up at Mat and his men, bloodlust clouding their eyes. It was an incongruous expression on the clean faces of men in neat vests and combed hair.

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz," mæt sɛd, swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl. "maʊn ʌp!"

"Blood and bloody ashes," Mat said, swinging into his saddle. "Mount up!"

hɑɹnən ən dɛlɑɹn niɾəd noʊ fɝðɝ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən. ðeɪ kɝst, ʃiðɪŋ sɔɹdz ən swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə sæɾəlz. ðə pæk ə vɪlɪdʒɝz sɝdʒ fɔɹwɝd, bʌt mæt ən tælmɑnz kʌɾ ɔf ði ətæk. mæt tʃɹaɪd tə ɡoʊ fəɹ wundɪŋ bloʊz oʊnli, bʌt ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz wɝ dɪsɛptɪvli stʃɹɔŋ ən fæst, ən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf faɪɾɪŋ dʒʌs tə kip əm fɹəm pʊlɪŋ ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl. hi kɝst, ɹɪlʌktənli bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wil kɪlɪŋ bloʊz, teɪkɪŋ tu ʌv ðə mɛn wɪð swips tə ðə nɛk. pɪps kɪkt aʊɾ ən nɑkt ənʌðɝ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ə huf tə ðə hɛd. ɪn ə fju moʊməns, hɑɹnən ən dɛlɑɹn dʒɔɪn ðə faɪt.

Harnan and Delarn needed no further instruction. They cursed, sheathing swords and swinging into saddles. The pack of villagers surged forward, but Mat and Talmanes cut off the attack. Mat tried to go for wounding blows only, but the villagers were deceptively strong and fast, and he found himself fighting just to keep them from pulling him out of the saddle. He cursed, reluctantly beginning to wield killing blows, taking two of the men with sweeps to the neck. Pips kicked out and knocked another to the ground with a hoof to the head. In a few moments, Harnan and Delarn joined the fight.

ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz dɪdn bæk əweɪ. ðeɪ kɛp faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə fɹɛnzi əntɪl ði ɪntaɪɝ pæk ʌv eɪt hæd dʒɹɑpt. mæts soʊlʒɝz fɔt wɪð waɪd-aɪd tɛɹɝ, ən mæt dɪdn bleɪm ðɛm. ɪt wɑz fleɪmɪŋ ɪɹi, siɪŋ kɑmən vɪlɪdʒɝz ɹiæk laɪk ðɪs! ðəɹ dɪdn sim tə bi ən aʊns ə hjumænɪɾi lɛft ɪn ðɛm. ðeɪ spoʊk oʊnli ɪn ɡɹʌns, hɪsɪz, ən skɹimz, ðɛɹ feɪsəz peɪntəd wɪð æŋɡɝ ən blʌdlʌst.

The villagers didn't back away. They kept fighting in a frenzy until the entire pack of eight had dropped. Mat's soldiers fought with wide-eyed terror, and Mat didn't blame them. It was flaming eerie, seeing common villagers react like this! There didn't seem to be an ounce of humanity left in them. They spoke only in grunts, hisses, and screams, their faces painted with anger and bloodlust.

naʊ ði ʌðɝ vɪlɪdʒɝz - ðoʊz nɑt dɝɛkli ətækɪŋ mæts mɛn - stɑɹɾəd fɔɹmɪŋ ɪndə pæks, slɔɾɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹups smɔlɝ ðən ðɛmsɛlvz baɪ blʌdʒoʊnɪŋ ðɛm, klɔɪŋ ðɛm, baɪɾɪŋ ðɛm. ɪt wɑz ənɝvɪŋ.

Now the other villagers - those not directly attacking Mat's men - started forming into packs, slaughtering the groups smaller than themselves by bludgeoning them, clawing them, biting them. It was unnerving.

əz mæt wɑtʃt, ə bɑɾi bɹoʊk θɹu wʌn ə ðə tævɝn wɪndoʊ fɹeɪmz. ðə kɔɹps ɹoʊl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, nɛk bɹoʊkən. ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, bɑɹldən stʊd wɪð waɪld, nɪɹli ɪnhjumən aɪz. hi skɹimd ɪndə ðə naɪt, ðən sɔ mæt ən - fəɹ dʒʌst ə moʊmənt - sim tə ʃoʊ ə hɪn ə ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən. ðən ɪt wɑz ɡɔn, ən ðə meɪɝ bɛloʊɾ əɡɛn, ɹʌnɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə lip θɹu ðə bɹoʊkən wɪndoʊ ən ətæk ə pɛɹ ə mɛn huz bæks wɝ tɝnd.

As Mat watched, a body broke through one of the tavern window frames. The corpse rolled to the ground, neck broken. On the other side, Barlden stood with wild, nearly inhuman eyes. He screamed into the night, then saw Mat and - for just a moment - seemed to show a hint of recognition. Then it was gone, and the mayor bellowed again, running forward to leap through the broken window and attack a pair of men whose backs were turned.

"muv!" mæt sɛd, ɹɪɹɪŋ pɪps əz ənʌðɝ pæk ə vɪlɪdʒɝz sɔ hɪm.

"Move!" Mat said, rearing Pips as another pack of villagers saw him.

"ðə ɡoʊld!" tælmɑnz sɛd.

"The gold!" Talmanes said.

"bɝn ðə ɡoʊld!" mæt sɛd. "wi kən wɪn mɔɹ, ən ðət fuɾ ɪzənt wɝθ əɹ lɪvz. ɡoʊ!"

"Burn the gold!" Mat said. "We can win more, and that food isn't worth our lives. Go!"

tælmɑnz ən ðə soʊlʒɝz tɝn ðɛɹ maʊns ən ɡæləp daʊn ðə stʃɹit, mæt kɪkɪŋ pɪps tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm, livɪŋ ðə ɡoʊld ən wæɡən bɪhaɪnd. ɪt wɑznt wɝθ ðɛɹ laɪvz - ɪf pɑsəbəl, hid bɹɪŋ ði ɑɹmi ɪn ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ɪt. bʌt ðeɪ hæd tə sɝvaɪv fɝst.

Talmanes and the soldiers turned their mounts and galloped down the street, Mat kicking Pips to join them, leaving the gold and wagon behind. It wasn't worth their lives - if possible, he'd bring the army in on the morrow to recover it. But they had to survive first.

ðeɪ ɡæləp fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm, ən mæt sloʊɾ əm ət ðə nɛks kɔɹnɝ, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə hænd. hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz wɝ stɪl kʌmɪŋ, bʌt ðə ɡæləp hæd lɛft əm bɪhaɪn fəɹ naʊ.

They galloped for a short time, and Mat slowed them at the next corner, holding up a hand. He glanced over his shoulder. The villagers were still coming, but the gallop had left them behind for now.

"aɪm stɪl bleɪmɪŋ ju," tælmɑnz sɛd.

"I'm still blaming you," Talmanes said.

"aɪ θɔt jə laɪk faɪɾɪŋ," mæt sɛd.

"I thought you liked fighting," Mat said.

"aɪ laɪk səm faɪts," tælmɑnz sɛd. "ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild əɹ ə naɪs bɑɹ faɪt. ðɪs . . . ðɪs ɪz ɪnseɪn." ðə pæk ə vɪlɪdʒɝz bɪhaɪn hæd fɔlən tə ɔl fɔɹz ən wɝ muvɪŋ ɪn ə stʃɹeɪnʒ loʊp.

"I like some fights," Talmanes said. "On the battlefield or a nice bar fight. This . . . this is insane." The pack of villagers behind had fallen to all fours and were moving in a strange lope.

tælmɑnz ʃɪvɝd vɪzəbli.

Talmanes shivered visibly.

ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɪnʌf laɪt tə si baɪ. naʊ ðət ðə sʌn hæd sɛt, ðoʊz maʊntənz ən ðə ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz blɑkt wʌt laɪt ɹɪmeɪnd. læntɝnz laɪn mɛni ʌv ðə stʃɹits, bʌɾ ɪt dɪdn lʊk əz ɪf ɛniwʌn wəd bi laɪɾɪŋ ðɛm.

There was barely enough light to see by. Now that the sun had set, those mountains and the gray clouds blocked what light remained. Lanterns lined many of the streets, but it didn't look as if anyone would be lighting them.

"mæt, ðəɹ ɡeɪnɪŋ," tælmɑnz sɛd, sɔɹd hɛld ət ðə ɹɛɾi.

"Mat, they're gaining," Talmanes said, sword held at the ready.

"ðɪs ɪzən dʒʌst əbaʊɾ əɹ weɪdʒɝ," mæt sɛd, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə skɹimz ən ʃaʊts. ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm ɔl ɝaʊn ðə vɪlədʒ. daʊn ə saɪd ɹoʊd, ə kʌpəl ə stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ bɑɾiz bɝs θɹu ði ʌpɝ wɪndoʊ ʌv ə haʊs. ðeɪ wɝ wɪmən, klɔɪŋ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ əz ðeɪ fɛl, kɹæʃɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ə sɪkənɪŋ θʌd. ðeɪ stɑp muvɪŋ.

"This isn't just about our wager," Mat said, listening to the screams and shouts. They came from all around the village. Down a side road, a couple of struggling bodies burst through the upper window of a house. They were women, clawing at each other as they fell, crashing to the ground with a sickening thud. They stopped moving.

"kʌm ɑn," mæt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ pɪps. "wiv ɡɑt tə faɪn tɑm ən ðə wɪmən." ðeɪ ɡæləp daʊn ə saɪd stʃɹit ðət wəɾ ɪntɝsɛkt wɪð ðə meɪn θɝoʊfɛɹ, pæsɪŋ pæks ə mɛn ən wɪmən faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡʌɾɝz. ə fæt mæn wɪð blʌɾid tʃiks stʌmbəld ɪndə ðə ɹoʊd, ən mæt ɹɪlʌktənli ɹoʊɾ ɪm daʊn. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni pipəl faɪɾɪŋ ət ðə saɪdz fəɹ ɪm tə ɹɪsk liɾɪŋ ɪz mɛn ɝaʊn ðə pʊɹ ful. mæt ivən sɔ tʃɪlʒɹən faɪɾɪŋ, baɪɾɪŋ ət ðə lɛɡz ə ðoʊz lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðeɪ, θɹɑɾəlɪŋ ðoʊz ðɛɹ oʊn eɪdʒ.

"Come on," Mat said, turning Pips. "We've got to find Thom and the women." They galloped down a side street that would intersect with the main thoroughfare, passing packs of men and women fighting in the gutters. A fat man with bloodied cheeks stumbled into the road, and Mat reluctantly rode him down. There were too many people fighting at the sides for him to risk leading his men around the poor fool. Mat even saw children fighting, biting at the legs of those larger than they, throttling those their own age.

"ði ɪntaɪɝ blʌɾi taʊn əz ɡɔn ɪnseɪn," mæt mʌɾɝd ɡɹɪmli əz ðə fɔɹ ə ðɛm bæɹəld ɑntu ðə meɪn stʃɹiɾ ən tɝn təwɔɹd ðə faɪn ɪn. ðeɪd pɪk ʌp ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðən swɪŋ aʊɾ istwɝd fəɹ tɑm, əz ɪz ɪn wɑz ðə moʊs dɪstənt.

"The entire bloody town has gone insane," Mat muttered grimly as the four of them barreled onto the main street and turned toward the fine inn. They'd pick up the Aes Sedai, then swing out eastward for Thom, as his inn was the most distant.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðə meɪn stʃɹit wɑz wɝs ðən ðə wʌn mæt hæd lɛft. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs kəmplitli dɑɹk naʊ. ɪndid, ɪt sim tə hɪm ðət ðə dɑɹknəs hæd kʌm tu kwɪkli hɪɹ. ənnətʃɝəli swɪft. ðə ɹoʊdz lɛŋθ skwɝmd wɪð ʃædoʊz, fɪɡjɝz bæɾəlɪŋ, skɹitʃɪŋ, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ ɪn ðə dipənɪŋ ɡlum.

Unfortunately, the main street was worse than the one Mat had left. It was almost completely dark now. Indeed, it seemed to him that the darkness had come too quickly here. Unnaturally swift. The road's length squirmed with shadows, figures battling, screeching, struggling in the deepening gloom.

ɪn ðət dɑɹknəs, ðə faɪts lʊkt ət taɪmz tə bi sɑləd, sɪŋɡəl kɹitʃɝz - hɔɹɪfɪk mɑnstʃɹɑsəɾiz wɪð ə dʌzən weɪvɪŋ lɪmz ən ə hʌnʒɹəd maʊðz tə skɹim fɹəm ðə blæknəs.

In that darkness, the fights looked at times to be solid, single creatures - horrific monstrosities with a dozen waving limbs and a hundred mouths to scream from the blackness.

mæt spɝd pɪps fɔɹwɝd. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də bʌt tʃɑɹdʒ daʊn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt.

Mat spurred Pips forward. There was nothing to do but charge down the middle of it.

"laɪt," tælmɑnz jɛld əz ðeɪ ɡæləp təwɔɹd ði ɪn. "laɪt!"

"Light," Talmanes yelled as they galloped toward the inn. "Light!"

mæt ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ ən lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn pɪps, spɪɹ hɛl kloʊs tə hɪz saɪɾ əz i ɹoʊd θɹu ðə naɪtmɛɹ. ɹɔɹz ʃʊk ðə dɑɹknəs ən bɑɾiz ɹoʊld əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit. mæt ʃɪvɝɾ ət ðə hɔɹɝ ʌv ɪt, kɝsɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. ðə naɪɾ ɪtsɛlf sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə smʌðɝ ðɛm, tə stʃɹæŋɡəl ðɛm, ən tə spɑn bists ə blæknəs ən mɝɾɝ.

Mat gritted his teeth and leaned forward on Pips, spear held close to his side as he rode through the nightmare. Roars shook the darkness and bodies rolled across the street. Mat shivered at the horror of it, cursing under his breath. The night itself seemed to be trying to smother them, to strangle them, and to spawn beasts of blackness and murder.

pɪps ən ði ʌðɝ hɔɹsəz wɝ wɛl tʃɹeɪnd, ən ðə fɔɹ ə ðɛm tʃɑɹdʒ stʃɹeɪt daʊn ðə stʃɹit.

Pips and the other horses were well trained, and the four of them charged straight down the street.

mæt nɛɹoʊli əvɔɪɾəd biɪŋ pʊl fɹəm ðə sæɾəl əz dɑɹk fɔɹmz lɛp fəɹ ɪz lɛɡz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə jæŋk ɪm fɹi. ðeɪ skɹimd ən hɪst, laɪk lidʒənz ə ðə dʒɹaʊn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl ɪm daʊn ɪndə ə dip, ənɝθli si.

Mat narrowly avoided being pulled from the saddle as dark forms leapt for his legs, trying to yank him free. They screamed and hissed, like legions of the drowned trying to pull him down into a deep, unearthly sea.

bɪsaɪd mæt, dɛlɑɹnz hɔɹs sʌɾənli pʊl tə ə hɔlt, ðɛn, əz ə mæs ə blæk fɪɡjɝz lɛpt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪt, ðə ɡɛldɪŋ ɹɪɹɾ ɪn pænɪk, θɹoʊɪŋ dɛlɑɹn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl.

Beside Mat, Delarn's horse suddenly pulled to a halt, then, as a mass of black figures leaped in front of it, the gelding reared in panic, throwing Delarn from his saddle.

mæt ɹeɪn ɪn pɪps, tɝnɪŋ ət ðə mænz skɹim, wɪtʃ wɑz sʌmhaʊ mɔɹ dɪstɪŋkt ən mɔɹ hjumən ðən ðə haʊlz ɝaʊn ðɛm.

Mat reined in Pips, turning at the man's scream, which was somehow more distinct and more human than the howls around them.

"mæt!" tælmɑnz jɛld, tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ pæst. "kip ɡoʊɪŋ! wi kæn stɑp!"

"Mat!" Talmanes yelled, charging past. "Keep going! We can't stop!"

noʊ, mæt θɔt, ʃʌvɪŋ daʊn ɪz pænɪk. noʊ, aɪm nɑt livɪŋ sʌmwʌn tə ðɪs. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən ɪɡnɔɹd tælmɑnz, kɪkɪŋ pɪps bæk təwɔɹd ðə blæk klɑɾ ə bɑɾiz wɛɹ dɛlɑɹn hæd fɔlən. swɛt spɹeɪd fɹəm ɪz fɔɹhɛd, tʃɪl baɪ ðə wɪn ə ðə ɡæləp. moʊnz, skɹimz, ən hɪsɪz ɔl ɝaʊn ɪm sim tə dɪsɛn ɑn hɪm.

No, Mat thought, shoving down his panic. No, I'm not leaving someone to this. He took a deep breath and ignored Talmanes, kicking Pips back toward the black clot of bodies where Delarn had fallen. Sweat sprayed from his forehead, chilled by the wind of the gallop. Moans, screams, and hisses all around him seemed to descend on him.

mæt ɹɔɹɾ ən θɹu hɪmsɛlf fɹəm pɪps' bæk - hi kʊdn bɹɪŋ ɪz maʊn ɪn wɪθaʊt ɹɪskɪŋ tʃɹæmplɪŋ ðə mæn i wɑntəd tə seɪv. hi heɪɾəd faɪɾɪŋ ɪn dɑɹknəs, hi blʌɾi heɪɾəd ɪt. hi ətæk ðoʊz dɑɹk fɪɡjɝz, huz feɪsəz i kʊdn si seɪv fəɹ ən əkeɪʒənəl flæʃ ə tiθ əɹ ɪnseɪn aɪz ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə daɪɪŋ laɪt. ɪt ɹimaɪndəd hɪm, bɹifli, ʌv ənʌðɝ naɪt, kɪlɪŋ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ɪn ðə dɑɹk.

Mat roared and threw himself from Pips' back - he couldn't bring his mount in without risking trampling the man he wanted to save. He hated fighting in darkness, he bloody hated it. He attacked those dark figures, whose faces he couldn't see save for an occasional flash of teeth or insane eyes reflecting the dying light. It reminded him, briefly, of another night, killing Shadowspawn in the dark.

seɪv ðiz fɪɡjɝz i fɔt dɪdn əv ðə ɡɹeɪs ʌv ə mɹdʒɹɑl. ðeɪ dɪdn ivən əv ðə koʊɔɹɾəneɪʃən ə tʃɹɑləks.

Save these figures he fought didn't have the grace of a Myrddraal. They didn't even have the coordination of Trollocs.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɪt simd mæt fɔt ðə ʃædoʊz ðɛmsɛlvz - ʃædoʊz meɪd baɪ spʌɾɝɪŋ faɪɹlaɪt, ɹændəm ən ənkoʊɔɹɾəneɪtɪd, jɛɾ ɔl ðə mɔɹ dɛdli fəɹ ɪz ɪnəbɪlɪɾi tə æntɪsəpeɪt ðɛm. hi nɛɹoʊli ɪskeɪpt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪz skʌl kɹʌʃt baɪ ətæks ðət meɪd noʊ sɛns. dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ, ðoʊz ətæks wʊɾə bɪn læfəbəl, bʌt fɹəm ðɪs dɑɹkən pæk ə mɛn - ən wɪmən - hu dɪdn kɛɹ wʌt ðeɪ hɪɾ əɹ u ðeɪ hɝt, ði ətæks wɝ oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ. mæt faʊn hɪmsɛlf faɪɾɪŋ dʒʌs tə steɪ əlaɪv, spɪnɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn waɪɾ ɑɹks, juzɪŋ ɪt tə tʃɹɪp əz ɔfən əz i juzd ɪt tə kɪl. ɪf sʌmθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, hi stʃɹʌk. haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz i gɑnə faɪn dɛlɑɹn ɪn ðɪs!

For a moment, it seemed Mat fought the shadows themselves - shadows made by sputtering firelight, random and uncoordinated, yet all the more deadly for his inability to anticipate them. He narrowly escaped getting his skull crushed by attacks that made no sense. During the day, those attacks would have been laughable, but from this darkened pack of men - and women - who didn't care what they hit or who they hurt, the attacks were overwhelming. Mat found himself fighting just to stay alive, spinning his ashandarei in wide arcs, using it to trip as often as he used it to kill. If something moved in the darkness, he struck. How in the light was he going to find Delarn in this!

ə ʃædoʊ muv dʒʌst ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, ən mæt ɪnstənli ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ə sɔɹd-fɔɹm. ɹæt nɔɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪn? ə vɪlɪdʒɝ wʊdnt noʊ ðæt. ɡʊd mæn!

A shadow moved just a short distance away, and Mat instantly recognized a sword-form. Rat Gnawing the Grain? A villager wouldn't know that. Good man!

mæt spʌn təwɔɹd ðət ʃædoʊ, slæʃɪŋ tu ʌðɝ ʃædoʊz əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst, ɝnɪŋ ɡɹʌns ən haʊlz ə peɪn. dɛlɑɹnz fɪɡjɝ fɛl bɪniθ ə paɪl ə sɛvɹəl ʌðɝz, ən mæt bɛloʊɾ ɪn dɪnaɪəl, lipɪŋ əkɹɔs ə fɔlən bɑɾi ən lændɪŋ wɪð ɪz spɪɹ dɪsɛndɪŋ ɪn ə bɹɔd swip. ʃædoʊz blɛd wɛɹ i stʃɹʌk, ðə blʌd dʒʌst ənʌðɝ pætʃ ə dɑɹknəs, ən mæt juz ðə bʌɾ ə hɪz wɛpən tə bit bæk ənʌðɝ. hi ɹitʃt daʊn, pʊlɪŋ wʌn ə ðə ʃædoʊz tə ɪts fit, ən hɝɾ ə mʌɾɝd kɝs. ɪt wɑz dɛlɑɹn.

Mat spun toward that shadow, slashing two other shadows across the chest, earning grunts and howls of pain. Delarn's figure fell beneath a pile of several others, and Mat bellowed in denial, leaping across a fallen body and landing with his spear descending in a broad sweep. Shadows bled where he struck, the blood just another patch of darkness, and Mat used the butt of his weapon to beat back another. He reached down, pulling one of the shadows to its feet, and heard a muttered curse. It was Delarn.

"kʌm ɑn," mæt sɛd, pʊlɪŋ ðə mæn təwɔɹd pɪps, hu stʊd fɝm, snɔɹɾɪŋ, ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ði ətækɪŋ mɛn sim tə ɪɡnɔɹ ænəməlz, wɪtʃ wɑz fɔɹtʃənət. mæt ʃʌv ðə stʌmbəlɪŋ dɛlɑɹn təwɔɹd ðə hɔɹs, ðən tɝn ən ɛnɡeɪdʒ ðə pæk hid noʊn wəd tʃeɪs æftɝ hɪm. əɡɛn, mæt dænst wɪð ðə dɑɹknəs, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsɪnɡeɪdʒ soʊ ðəɾ i kəd klaɪm ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. hi ɹɪskt ə ɡlæns oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən faʊn ðət dɛlɑɹn hæd mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɑntu pɪps'

"Come on," Mat said, pulling the man toward Pips, who stood firm, snorting, in the darkness. The attacking men seemed to ignore animals, which was fortunate. Mat shoved the stumbling Delarn toward the horse, then turned and engaged the pack he'd known would chase after him. Again, Mat danced with the darkness, striking again and again, trying to disengage so that he could climb into the saddle. He risked a glance over his shoulder, and found that Delarn had managed to get onto Pips'

bæk - bʌt ðə soʊlʒɝ sæt slʌmpt, ə hʌɾəld maʊnd. haʊ bædli wɑz i wundəd? hi bɛɹli simd eɪbəl tə kip hɪmsɛlf əpɹaɪt. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!

back - but the soldier sat slumped, a huddled mound. How badly was he wounded? He barely seemed able to keep himself upright. Blood and bloody ashes!

mæt tɝn bæk tə ði ətækɝz, spɪnɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs əm bæk. bʌt ðeɪ dɪdn kɛɹ əbaʊt biɪŋ wundəd, ðeɪ dɪdn kɛɹ haʊ deɪnʒɝəs mæt wɑz. ðeɪ dʒʌs kɛp kʌmɪŋ! sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪm. kʌmɪŋ əɾ ɪm fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪd. blʌɾi æʃəz! hi twɪstəd dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə si ə dɑɹk ʃeɪp ɹʌʃ ɪm fɹəm bɪhaɪnd.

Mat turned back to the attackers, spinning his spear, trying to force them back. But they didn't care about being wounded, they didn't care how dangerous Mat was. They just kept coming! Surrounding him. Coming at him from every side. Bloody ashes! He twisted just in time to see a dark shape rush him from behind.

sʌmθɪŋ flæʃt ɪn ðə naɪt, ɹəflɛktɪŋ səm vɛɹi dɪstən laɪt. ðə dɑɹk fɪɡjɝ bɪhaɪn mæt slʌmp tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ənʌðɝ flæʃ, ən wʌn ə ðə wʌnz ɪn fɹʌn ə mæt fɛl. sʌɾənli, ə fɪɡjɝ ɑn ə waɪt hɔɹs ɹʌʃt pæst, ən ənʌðɝ naɪf flæʃt ɪn ði ɛɹ, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ə θɝd mæn.

Something flashed in the night, reflecting some very distant light. The dark figure behind Mat slumped to the ground. Another flash, and one of the ones in front of Mat fell. Suddenly, a figure on a white horse rushed past, and another knife flashed in the air, dropping a third man.

"tɑm!" mæt kɔld, ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ ðə kloʊk.

"Thom!" Mat called, recognizing the cloak.

"ɡɛɾ ɑn jəɹ hɔɹs!" tɑmz vɔɪs kɔl bæk. "aɪm ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ə naɪvz!"

"Get on your horse!" Thom's voice called back. "I'm running out of knives!"

mæt swɛpt aʊt wɪð ɪz spɪɹ, dʒɹɑpɪŋ tu mɔɹ vɪlɪdʒɝz, ðən dæʃt fɔɹwɝɾ ən lɛpt ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl, tʃɹʌstɪŋ tɑm tə kʌvɝ ɪz ɹitʃɹit. ɪndid, hi hɝɾ ə fju kɹaɪz ə peɪn fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, ə θʌndɝɪŋ saʊn ɑn ðə ɹoʊɾ ənaʊns ði ɪmənən əpɹoʊtʃ ə hɔɹsəz. mæt pʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl əz ðə kɹitʃɝz tɔɹ θɹu ðə blæk mɝæs, skæɾɝɪŋ ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz.

Mat swept out with his spear, dropping two more villagers, then dashed forward and leaped into his saddle, trusting Thom to cover his retreat. Indeed, he heard a few cries of pain from behind. A moment later, a thundering sound on the road announced the imminent approach of horses. Mat pulled himself into his saddle as the creatures tore through the black morass, scattering the villagers.

"mæt, jə ful!" tælmɑnz ʃaʊɾəd fɹəm wʌn ə ðə hɔɹsəz, bɛɹli vɪzəbəl əz ə sɪləwɛɾ əɡɛns ðə naɪt.

"Mat, you fool!" Talmanes shouted from one of the horses, barely visible as a silhouette against the night.

mæt smaɪld ɡɹeɪtfəli ət tælmɑnz, tɝnɪŋ pɪps, ən kɑt dɛlɑɹn əz ðə mæn ɔlmoʊst slɪd fɹi.

Mat smiled gratefully at Talmanes, turning Pips, and caught Delarn as the man almost slid free.

ðə ɹɛdɑɹm wɑz əlaɪv, fəɹ i stʃɹʌɡəld wikli, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə slɪk wɛt pætʃ əɾ ɪz saɪd. mæt hɛl ðə mæn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs ən kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ pɪps wɪð ə kwɪk twɪst ə ðə niz. hi dɪdnt noʊ hɔɹsbæk bæɾəl kəmænz hɪmsɛlf, bʌt ðoʊz blæstəd mɛmɹiz dɪd, ən soʊ hid tʃɹeɪn pɪps tə oʊbeɪ.

The Redarm was alive, for he struggled weakly, but there was a slick wet patch at his side. Mat held the man in front of him, ignoring the reins in the darkness and controlling Pips with a quick twist of the knees. He didn't know horseback battle commands himself, but those blasted memories did, and so he'd trained Pips to obey.

tɑm ɡæləpt pæst, ən mæt tɝn pɪps tə fɑloʊ, stɛɾiɪŋ dɛlɑɹn wɪð wʌn hæn ən kæɹiɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. tælmɑnz ən hɑɹnən ɹoʊd tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm, tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ ə mædnəs təwɔɹd ði ɪn ət ði ɛnd.

Thom galloped past, and Mat turned Pips to follow, steadying Delarn with one hand and carrying his spear in the other. Talmanes and Harnan rode to either side of him, charging down the corridor of madness toward the inn at the end.

"kʌm ɑn, mæn," mæt wɪspɝd tə dɛlɑɹn. "hæŋ ɑn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ dʒʌst əhɛd. ðəl fɪks jə ʌp."

"Come on, man," Mat whispered to Delarn. "Hang on. The Aes Sedai are just ahead. They'll fix you up."

dɛlɑɹn wɪspɝd sʌmθɪŋ bæk.

Delarn whispered something back.

mæt lin fɔɹwɝd. "wʌt wɑz ðæt?"

Mat leaned forward. "What was that?"

". . . ən tɔs ðə daɪs əntɪl wi flaɪ," dɛlɑɹn wɪspɝd. "tə dæns wɪð dʒæk oʊ' ðə ʃædoʊz. . . ."

". . . and toss the dice until we fly," Delarn whispered. "To dance with Jak o' the Shadows. . . ."

"ɡɹeɪt," mæt mʌɾɝd. ðəɹ wɝ laɪts əhɛd, ən i kəd si ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ði ɪn.

"Great," Mat muttered. There were lights ahead, and he could see they were coming from the inn.

pɝhæps ðeɪd faɪnd wʌn pleɪs ɪn ðɪs fleɪmɪŋ vɪlədʒ wɛɹ ðə pipəlz bɹeɪnz hædn tɝn ɪnsaɪɾ aʊt.

Perhaps they'd find one place in this flaming village where the people's brains hadn't turned inside out.

bʌt noʊ. ðoʊz bɝsts ə laɪt wɝ fəmɪljɝ. bɔlz ə faɪɝ, flæʃɪŋ ɪn ði ʌpɝ-stɔɹi wɪndoʊz ə ði ɪn.

But no. Those bursts of light were familiar. Balls of fire, flashing in the upper-story windows of the inn.

"wɛl," tælmɑnz noʊɾəd fɹəm ɪz lɛft, "lʊks laɪk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stɪl lɪv. ðæts sʌmθɪŋ, ət list."

"Well," Talmanes noted from his left, "looks like the Aes Sedai still live. That's something, at least."

fɪɡjɝz klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə fɹʌn ə ði ɪn, faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ðɛɹ fɔɹmz piɹiɑɾɪkəli lɪt fɹəm əbʌv baɪ ðə flæʃɪz ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz.

Figures clustered around the front of the inn, fighting in the darkness, their forms periodically lit from above by the flashes in the windows.

"ɹaʊn tə ðə bæk," tɑm sədʒɛstəd.

"Round to the back," Thom suggested.

"ɡoʊ," mæt sɛd tə ðɛm, tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ pæs ðə faɪɾɪŋ fɪɡjɝz. tælmɑnz, tɑm ən hɑɹnən fɑloʊd kloʊs ɑn pɪps' hʊvz. mæt blɛst ɪz lʌk ðət ðeɪ dɪdn hɪɾ ə hoʊl əɹ ɹʌɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn əz ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə sɑftɝ ɝθ kʌmɪŋ ɝaʊn bɪhaɪn ði ɪn. ðə hɔɹsəz kəɾ izəli hæv tʃɹɪpt ən bɹoʊkən ə lɛɡ, θɹoʊɪŋ ɔl ə ðɛm ɪndə dɪzæstɝ.

"Go," Mat said to them, charging past the fighting figures. Talmanes, Thom and Harnan followed close on Pips' hooves. Mat blessed his luck that they didn't hit a hole or rut in the ground as they crossed the softer earth coming around behind the inn. The horses could easily have tripped and broken a leg, throwing all of them into disaster.

ðə bæk ə ði ɪn wɑz saɪlənt, ən mæt ɹeɪn ɪn. tɑm lɛp fɹəm ɪz hɔɹs, hɪz ədʒɪləɾi dɪfaɪɪŋ ɪz ɝliɝ kəmpleɪns əbaʊɾ ɪz eɪdʒ. hi tʊk ʌp pəzɪʃən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ tə si ðət ðeɪ wɝn fɑloʊd.

The back of the inn was silent, and Mat reined in. Thom leaped from his horse, his agility defying his earlier complaints about his age. He took up position watching the side of the building to see that they weren't followed.

"hɑɹnən!" mæt sɛd, θɹʌstɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ təwɔɹd ðə steɪbəlz. "ɡɛt ðə wɪmənz hɔɹsəz aʊɾ ən ɹɛɾi ðɛm. sæɾəl əm ɪf jə kæn, bʌt bi ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt ðoʊz ɪf wɪv tə. laɪt wɪlɪŋ, wi woʊn əv tə ɹaɪd fɑɹ, dʒʌst ə maɪl əɹ soʊ tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ ən əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs ɪnsænəɾi."

"Harnan!" Mat said, thrusting his spear toward the stables. "Get the women's horses out and ready them. Saddle them if you can, but be ready to go without those if we have to. Light willing, we won't have to ride far, just a mile or so to get out of the village and away from this insanity."

hɑɹnən səluɾəd ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ðən dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən dæʃt oʊvɝ tə ðə steɪbəlz. mæt weɪɾəd lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə dətɝmən ðət noʊbɑdi wɑz gɑnə dʒʌmp aʊɾ əɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə dɑɹknəs, ðən spoʊk tə dɛlɑɹn, stɪl hɛld ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. "ju stɪl kɑnʃəs?"

Harnan saluted in the darkness, then dismounted and dashed over to the stables. Mat waited long enough to determine that nobody was going to jump out at him from the darkness, then spoke to Delarn, still held in front of him. "You still conscious?"

dɛlɑɹn nɑɾəd wikli. "jɛs, mæt. bʌɾ aɪv teɪkən ə ɡʌt waʊnd. aɪ. . . ."

Delarn nodded weakly. "Yes, Mat. But I've taken a gut wound. I. . . ."

"wil ɡɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ," mæt sɛd. "ɔl jə nid tə də ɪz sɪt ɹaɪt hɪɹ. steɪ ɪn ðə sæɾəl, ɔl ɹaɪt?"

"We'll get the Aes Sedai," Mat said. "All you need to do is sit right here. Stay in the saddle, all right?"

dɛlɑɹn nɑɾəd əɡɛn. mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ət ðə wiknəs ɪn ðə mænz moʊʃənz, bʌt dɛlɑɹn tʊk pɪps'

Delarn nodded again. Mat hesitated at the weakness in the man's motions, but Delarn took Pips'

ɹeɪnz, ən sim dɪtɝmənd. soʊ mæt slɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ət ðə ɹɛɾi.

reins, and seemed determined. So Mat slid out of the saddle, holding his ashandarei at the ready.

"mæt," dɛlɑɹn sɛd fɹəm ðə sæɾəl.

"Mat," Delarn said from the saddle.

mæt tɝn bæk.

Mat turned back.

"θæŋk ju. fəɹ kʌmɪŋ bæk fəɹ mi."

"Thank you. For coming back for me."

"aɪ wɑzn gɑnə liv ə mæn tə ðæt," mæt sɛd, ʃɪvɝɪŋ. "daɪɪŋ ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild ɪz wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt tə daɪ aʊt ðɛɹ, ɪn ðət dɑɹknəs. . . . wɛl, aɪ wɑzn gɑnə lɛɾ ɪt hæpən. tælmɑnz! si ɪf jə kən faɪn səm laɪt."

"I wasn't going to leave a man to that," Mat said, shivering. "Dying on the battlefield is one thing, but to die out there, in that darkness. . . . Well, I wasn't going to let it happen. Talmanes! See if you can find some light."

"wɝkɪŋ ɑn ɪt," ðə kɛɹhinɪn sɛd fɹəm bɪsaɪd ði ɪnz bæk dɔɹ. hi hæd faʊn ə læntɝn hæŋɪŋ ðɛɹ. ə fju stʃɹaɪks ə flɪn ən stil leɪɾɝ, ən ə smɔl, sɑft ɡloʊ lɪt ðə bækjɑɹɾ ə ði ɪn.

"Working on it," the Cairhienin said from beside the inn's back door. He had found a lantern hanging there. A few strikes of flint and steel later, and a small, soft glow lit the backyard of the inn.

tælmɑnz kwɪkli kloʊz ðə ʃild, kipɪŋ ðə laɪt moʊsli hɪɾən.

Talmanes quickly closed the shield, keeping the light mostly hidden.

tɑm tʃɹɑɾəd bæk tə ðɛm. "noʊ wʌn fɑloʊɪŋ, mæt," hi sɛd.

Thom trotted back to them. "No one following, Mat," he said.

mæt nɑɾəd. baɪ ðə læntɝnlaɪt, hi kəd si ðət dɛlɑɹn wɑz ɪn bæd ʃeɪp. nɑt dʒʌs ðə ɡʌt waʊnd, bʌt skɹeɪps əkɹɔs ðə feɪs, ɹɪps ɪn ɪz junəfɔɹm, wʌn aɪ swoʊlən ʃʌt.

Mat nodded. By the lanternlight, he could see that Delarn was in bad shape. Not just the gut wound, but scrapes across the face, rips in his uniform, one eye swollen shut.

mæt wɪpt aʊɾ ə hæŋkɝtʃɪf ən pɹɛst ɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ɡʌt waʊnd, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd pɪps ən ɹitʃɪŋ ʌp tə ðə mæn ɪn ðə sæɾəl. "hoʊl ðɪs taɪt. haʊd ðə waʊn hæpən? ðeɪ doʊn juz wɛpənz."

Mat whipped out a handkerchief and pressed it against the gut wound, standing beside Pips and reaching up to the man in the saddle. "Hold this tight. How'd the wound happen? They don't use weapons."

"wʌn ɡɑt maɪ oʊn sɔɹɾ əweɪ fɹəm mi," dɛlɑɹn sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt. "hi juzd ɪt wɛl ɪnʌf wʌns i hæɾ ɪt."

"One got my own sword away from me," Delarn said with a grunt. "He used it well enough once he had it."

tælmɑnz hæɾ oʊpən ðə bæk dɔɹ ə ði ɪn. hi lʊk tə mæt ən nɑɾəd. ðə weɪ ɪnsaɪd wɑz klɪɹ.

Talmanes had opened the back door of the inn. He looked to Mat and nodded. The way inside was clear.

"wil bi bæk sun," mæt pɹɑməs dɛlɑɹn. hoʊldɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn ə lus ɡɹɪp, hi kɹɔs ðə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns tə ðə dɔɹ ən nɑɾəd tə tælmɑnz ən tɑm. ðə θɹi ʌv əm dʌkt ɪnsaɪd.

"We'll be back soon," Mat promised Delarn. Holding his ashandarei in a loose grip, he crossed the short distance to the door and nodded to Talmanes and Thom. The three of them ducked inside.

ðə dɔɹ lɛd tə ðə kɪtʃənz. mæt skæn ðə dɑɹk ɹum, ən tælmɑnz nʌdʒ hɪm, pɔɪntɪŋ ət sɛvɹəl lʌmps ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðə slɪvɝ ə læntɝn laɪt ɹɪvild ə pɛɹ ə kɪtʃən bɔɪz, bɛɹli tɛn jɪɹz oʊld, dɛɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðɛɹ nɛks twɪstəd. mæt ɡlænst əweɪ, stilɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, ən ɪntʃt ɪndə ðə ɹum. laɪt! oʊnli lædz, ən naʊ dɛd baɪ ðɪs ɪnsænəɾi.

The door led to the kitchens. Mat scanned the dark room, and Talmanes nudged him, pointing at several lumps on the floor. The sliver of lantern light revealed a pair of kitchen boys, barely ten years old, dead on the ground, their necks twisted. Mat glanced away, steeling himself, and inched into the room. Light! Only lads, and now dead by this insanity.

tɑm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd ɡɹɪmli, ən ðə θɹi ʌv əm kɹɛp fɔɹwɝd. ðeɪ faʊn ðə kʊk ɪn ðə nɛks hɔlweɪ, ɡɹʌntɪŋ əz i biɾ ɑn ðə hɛɾ ʌv wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ði ɪnkipɝ. ɪt wɑz ə mæn ɪn ə waɪɾ eɪpɹən, ət list. hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi dɛd. ðə fæt kʊk tɝn təwɔɹd mæt ən tælmɑnz ðə moʊmən ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə hɔlweɪ, fɛɹəl ɹeɪdʒ ɪn ɪz aɪz. mæt ɹɪlʌktənli stʃɹʌk, saɪlənsɪŋ ɪm bɪfɔɹ i kəd haʊl ən bɹɪŋ mɔɹ pipəl əɡɛns ðɛm.

Thom shook his head grimly, and the three of them crept forward. They found the cook in the next hallway, grunting as he beat on the head of what appeared to be the innkeeper. It was a man in a white apron, at least. He was already dead. The fat cook turned toward Mat and Talmanes the moment they entered the hallway, feral rage in his eyes. Mat reluctantly struck, silencing him before he could howl and bring more people against them.

"ðɛɹz faɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə stɛɹz," tælmɑnz sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝd.

"There's fighting on the stairs," Talmanes said, nodding forward.

"aɪl bɛt ðɛɹz ə sɝvəns' stɛɹwɛl," tɑm noʊɾəd. "ðɪs lʊks laɪk ə naɪs ɪnʌf pleɪs fəɹ ɪt."

"I'll bet there's a servants' stairwell," Thom noted. "This looks like a nice enough place for it."

ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, baɪ kʌɾɪŋ θɹu tu hɔlweɪz ɪn ðə bæk, ðeɪ faʊn ə nɛɹoʊ, ɹɪkəɾi stɛɹwɛl liɾɪŋ ʌp ɪndə dɑɹknəs. mæt tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən stɑɹɾəd ʌp ðə stɛɹz, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ət ðə ɹɛɾi. ði ɪn wɑz oʊnli tu stɔɹiz haɪ, ən ðə flæʃɪz hæd bɪn kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, nɪɹ ðə fɹʌnt.

Sure enough, by cutting through two hallways in the back, they found a narrow, rickety stairwell leading up into darkness. Mat took a deep breath, then started up the stairs, holding his ashandarei at the ready. The inn was only two stories high, and the flashes had been coming from the second floor, near the front.

ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, pʊʃɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə ði ækɹɪd sɛn ə bɝn flɛʃ. ðə hɔlweɪz hɪɹ wɝ ʌv wʊd, ðə ɡɹeɪn əbskjʊɹd baɪ θɪk waɪt peɪnt. ðə flɔɹ leɪ ʌndɝ ə dip tʃɛsnʌt kɑɹpət. mæt nɑɾəd tə tælmɑnz ən tɑm, ən - wɛpənz ət ðə ɹɛɾi - ðeɪ bɝst aʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹwɛl ən ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ.

They entered the second floor, pushing open the door to the acrid scent of burned flesh. The hallways here were of wood, the grain obscured by thick white paint. The floor lay under a deep chestnut carpet. Mat nodded to Talmanes and Thom, and - weapons at the ready - they burst out of the stairwell and into the hallway.

ɪmiɾiətli, ə bɔl ə faɪɝ whuʃt ɪn ðɛɹ dɝɛkʃən. mæt kɝst, θɹoʊɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bækwɝɾ ən ɪndə tælmɑnz, nɛɹoʊli əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə faɪɝ. tɑm flæɾənd hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə ɡlimənz ədʒɪləɾi, ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə faɪɝ. mæt ən tælmɑnz ɔlmoʊs tʌmbəl bæk daʊn ðə stɛɹz.

Immediately, a ball of fire whooshed in their direction. Mat cursed, throwing himself backward and into Talmanes, narrowly avoiding the fire. Thom flattened himself with a gleeman's agility, getting under the fire. Mat and Talmanes almost tumbled back down the stairs.

"blʌɾi æʃəz!" mæt jɛld ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk jəɹ duɪŋ?"

"Bloody ashes!" Mat yelled into the hallway. "What do you think you're doing?"

ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns. fɑloʊd, faɪnəli, baɪ dʒoʊlinz vɔɪs. "kɔθən?" ʃi kɔld.

There was silence. Followed, finally, by Joline's voice. "Cauthon?" she called.

"hu dʒju blʌɾi θɪŋk ɪɾ ɪz!" hi ʃaʊɾəd bæk.

"Who do you bloody think it is!" he shouted back.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ!" ʃi sɛd. "ju keɪm ɝaʊn soʊ kwɪkli, wɛpənz aʊt. ɑɹ jə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt kɪld?"

"I don't know!" she said. "You came around so quickly, weapons out. Are you trying to get killed?"

"wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɛskju ju!" mæt jɛld.

"We're trying to rescue you!" Mat yelled.

"du wi lʊk laɪk wi nid ɹɛskjuɪŋ?" keɪm ðə ɹɪspɑns.

"Do we look like we need rescuing?" came the response.

"wɛl, jəɹ stɪl hɪɹ, ɑɹən ju?" mæt kɔl bæk.

"Well, you're still here, aren't you?" Mat called back.

ðət wɑz mɛt wɪð saɪləns.

That was met with silence.

"oʊ, fəɹ laɪts seɪk," dʒoʊlin faɪnəli kɔl bæk. "wɪl jə kʌm aʊt hɪɹ?"

"Oh, for Light's sake," Joline finally called back. "Will you come out here?"

"jɔɹ nɑt gɑnə θɹoʊ ənʌðɝ faɪɝbɔl ət mi, ɑɹ ju?" mæt mʌɾɝd, stɛpɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ əz tɑm klaɪm tə hɪz fit, tælmɑnz fɑloʊɪŋ. hi faʊn ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ stændɪŋ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə waɪd, hænsəm stɛɹz ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə hɔlweɪ. tɛslɪn ən idɛzinə kəntɪnjud tə θɹoʊ faɪɝbɔlz daʊn əɾ ənsin vɪlɪdʒɝz bɪloʊ, ðɛɹ hɛɹ wɛt, ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz dɪʃɛvəld əz ɪf ðeɪd bɪn dɑn heɪstəli. dʒoʊlin wɔɹ oʊnli ən ɪnvɛləpɪŋ waɪt dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹoʊb, hɝ pɹɪɾi feɪs kɑm, hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ slɪk ən wɛɾ ən hæŋɪŋ daʊn oʊvɝ ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ. ðə ɹoʊb wɑz pɑɹɾəd slaɪtli ət ðə tɑp, ɡɪvɪŋ ə hɪn ʌv wʌt hɪɾ ɪnsaɪd. tælmɑnz wɪsəl sɔfli.

"You're not going to throw another fireball at me, are you?" Mat muttered, stepping out into the hallway as Thom climbed to his feet, Talmanes following. He found the three Aes Sedai standing at the head of the wide, handsome stairs at the other end of the hallway. Teslyn and Edesina continued to throw fireballs down at unseen villagers below, their hair wet, their dresses disheveled as if they'd been donned hastily. Joline wore only an enveloping white dressing robe, her pretty face calm, her dark hair slick and wet and hanging down over the front of her right shoulder. The robe was parted slightly at the top, giving a hint of what hid inside. Talmanes whistled softly.

"ʃiz nɑɾ ə wʊmən, tælmɑnz," mæt wɪspɝd wɔɹnɪŋli. "ʃiz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. doʊn θɪŋk ə hɝ əz ə wʊmən."

"She's not a woman, Talmanes," Mat whispered warningly. "She's an Aes Sedai. Don't think of her as a woman."

"aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪts hɑɹd." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən æɾəd, "bɝn mi."

"I'm trying, Mat," Talmanes said. "But it's hard." He hesitated, then added, "Burn me."

"bi kɛɹfəl əɹ ʃi wɪl," mæt sɛd, tʌɡɪŋ ɪz hæt daʊn slaɪtli ɪn ðə fɹʌnt. "ɪn fækt, ʃi nɪɹli dɪd ðət dʒʌst ə moʊmən əɡoʊ."

"Be careful or she will," Mat said, tugging his hat down slightly in the front. "In fact, she nearly did that just a moment ago."

tælmɑnz saɪd, ən ðə θɹi ʌv əm kɹɔs ðə hɔlweɪ tə ðə wɪmən. dʒoʊlinz tu wɔɹɾɝz ən ðə θɹi ɹɛdʒɹmz, hu hæd ðɛɹ wɛpənz aʊt, stʊd dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə beɪðɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ. ə dʌzən əɹ soʊ sɝvəns wɝ taɪɾ ʌp ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ: ə pɛɹ ə jʌŋ ɡɝlz - pɹɑbli beɪðɪŋ ətɛndəns - ən sɛvɹəl mɛn ɪn vɛsts ən tʃɹaʊzɝz. əpɛɹənli dʒoʊlinz dʒɹɛs hæd bɪn kʌt tə stʃɹɪps ən juz fəɹ bɑnz. ðə sɪlk wəd wɝk fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ðən wʊl taʊəlz. nɪɹ ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz, dʒʌs bɪloʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, mæt kəd bɛɹli meɪk aʊɾ ə klʌstɝ ə kɔɹpsəz ðət hæd fɔlən tə sɔɹdz, nɑt faɪɝ.

Talmanes sighed, and the three of them crossed the hallway to the women. Joline's two Warders and the three Redarms, who had their weapons out, stood just inside the bathing chamber. A dozen or so servants were tied up in the corner: a pair of young girls - probably bathing attendants - and several men in vests and trousers. Apparently Joline's dress had been cut to strips and used for bonds. The silk would work far better than wool towels. Near the top of the stairs, just below the Aes Sedai, Mat could barely make out a cluster of corpses that had fallen to swords, not fire.

dʒoʊlin aɪd mæt əz i əpɹoʊtʃt, ə lʊk ɪmplaɪɪŋ ðət ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ɔl ðɪs tə bi hɪz fɔl sʌmhaʊ. ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, kloʊzɪŋ ʌp ðə tɑp ə ðə ɹoʊb, ðoʊ hi wɑznt ʃʊɹ ɪf ðət wɑz kəz ə tælmɑnz' ɡɔkɪŋ əɹ ɪf ðə muv wɑz koʊɪnsədɛntəl.

Joline eyed Mat as he approached, a look implying that she considered all this to be his fault somehow. She folded her arms, closing up the top of the robe, though he wasn't sure if that was because of Talmanes' gawking or if the move was coincidental.

"wi nid tə muv," mæt toʊl ðə wɪmən. "ðə hoʊl sɪɾi hæz ɡɔn mæd."

"We need to move," Mat told the women. "The whole city has gone mad."

"wi kænt ɡoʊ," dʒoʊlin sɛd. "nɑɾ ən liv ðoʊz sɝvəns tə ðə mɑb. bɪsaɪdz, wi nid tə faɪn mæstɝ tɑbɹəɾ ən meɪk sɝɾən hiz seɪf."

"We can't go," Joline said. "Not and leave those servants to the mob. Besides, we need to find Master Tobrad and make certain he is safe."

"mæstɝ tɑbɹəɾ ɪz ði ɪnkipɝ?" mæt æskt. ə faɪɝbɔl whuʃt daʊn ðə stɛɹz.

"Master Tobrad is the innkeeper?" Mat asked. A fireball whooshed down the stairs.

"jɛs," dʒoʊlin sɛd.

"Yes," Joline said.

"tu leɪt," mæt sɛd. "hɪz bɹeɪnz ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi dɛkɝeɪɾɪŋ ðə wɔlz daʊnstɛɹz. lʊk, laɪk aɪ sɛd, ði ɪntaɪɝ vɪlədʒ ɪz kɹeɪzi. ðoʊz sɝvəns tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ju, dɪdn ðeɪ?"

"Too late," Mat said. "His brains are already decorating the walls downstairs. Look, like I said, the entire village is crazy. Those servants tried to kill you, didn't they?"

dʒoʊlin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "jɛs."

Joline hesitated. "Yes."

"liv ðɛm," mæt sɛd. "wi kæn də ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm."

"Leave them," Mat said. "We can't do anything for them."

"bʌɾ ɪf wi weɪɾ əntɪl dɔn . . ." dʒoʊlin sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli.

"But if we wait until dawn . . ." Joline said hesitantly.

"ænd wʌt?" mæt sɛd. "bɝn tə æʃ ɛvɹi pɝsən u tʃɹaɪz tə klaɪm ðoʊz stɛɹz? jəɹ meɪkɪŋ ə ɹʌkəs hɪɹ, ən ɪts dʒɹɔɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ pipəl. jəɹ gɑnə hæv tə kɪl əm ɔl tə stɑp ðɛm."

"And what?" Mat said. "Burn to ash every person who tries to climb those stairs? You're making a ruckus here, and it's drawing more and more people. You're going to have to kill them all to stop them."

dʒoʊlin ɡlænst ət ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən.

Joline glanced at the other two women.

"lʊk," mæt sɛd. "aɪ hæv ə wundəd ɹɛdɑɹm daʊn bɪloʊ, ən aɪ ɪntɛn tə ɡɛɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə ðɪs əlaɪv. jə kæn də ɛni ɡʊd fəɹ ðiz pipəl hɪɹ. aɪ səspɛk ðə mɛn hæd tə kɪl ðət ɡɹup ət ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz bɪfɔɹ jə ɔl fɛl θɹɛɾənd ɪnʌf tə juz ðə paʊɝ. jə noʊ haʊ dɪtɝmən ðeɪ ɑɹ."

"Look," Mat said. "I have a wounded Redarm down below, and I intend to get him out of this alive. You can't do any good for these people here. I suspect the men had to kill that group at the top of the stairs before you all felt threatened enough to use the Power. You know how determined they are."
