"ɔl ɹaɪt," dʒoʊlin sɛd. "aɪl kʌm. bʌt wɝ bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə tu sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz. blɹɪk ən fɛn kən kæɹi ðɛm."

"All right," Joline said. "I'll come. But we're bringing the two serving girls. Blaeric and Fen can carry them."

mæt saɪd - hiɾ əv laɪk ðə wɔɹɾɝz' bleɪdz fɹi tə hɛlp ɪn keɪs ðeɪ ɹæn ɪndə tʃɹʌbəl - bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ. hi nɑɾəd tə tælmɑnz ən tɑm, ən weɪɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli əz ðə wɔɹɾɝz pɪkt ʌp ðə tu baʊn sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz ən slʌŋ əm oʊvɝ ʃoʊldɝz. æftɝ ðæt, ðə hoʊl ɡɹup hʌsəl bæk daʊn ðə sɝvəns' stɛɹwɛl, tælmɑnz liɾɪŋ ən mæt ən ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz ət ðə ɹɪɹ. hi kəd hɪɹ skɹimz ðət saʊndəd hæf æŋɡɹi, hæf dʒɔɪəs əz ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz ət ðə beɪs ə ðə stɛɹz ɹilaɪz noʊ mɔɹ faɪɝ wəd fɔl. ðəɹ wɝ θʌmps ən ʃaʊts, fɑloʊd baɪ dɔɹz oʊpənɪŋ, ən mæt kɹɪnʒd, ɪmædʒənɪŋ ði ʌðɝ sɝvəns - lɛf taɪɾ ʌp ɪn ðə beɪðɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝ - fɔlɪŋ tə ðə kɹaʊd.

Mat sighed - he'd have liked the Warders' blades free to help in case they ran into trouble - but said nothing more. He nodded to Talmanes and Thom, and waited impatiently as the Warders picked up the two bound serving girls and slung them over shoulders. After that, the whole group hustled back down the servants' stairwell, Talmanes leading and Mat and the Redarms at the rear. He could hear screams that sounded half angry, half joyous as the villagers at the base of the stairs realized no more fire would fall. There were thumps and shouts, followed by doors opening, and Mat cringed, imagining the other servants - left tied up in the bathing chamber - falling to the crowd.

mæt ən ði ʌðɝz bɝst aʊɾ ɪndə ðə bækjɑɹɾ ə ði ɪn, oʊnli tə faɪn dɛlɑɹn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd pɪps. hɑɹnən nɛl bɪsaɪd hɪm, ən ðə bɪɹɾəd soʊlʒɝ lʊkt ʌp wɪð æŋzaɪəɾi. "mæt!" hi sɛd. "hi fɛl fɹəm ðə sæɾəl. aɪ - "

Mat and the others burst out into the backyard of the inn, only to find Delarn on the ground beside Pips. Harnan knelt beside him, and the bearded soldier looked up with anxiety. "Mat!" he said. "He fell from the saddle. I - "

idɛzinə kʌɾ ɪm ɔf, ɹʌʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ən nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd dɛlɑɹn. ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, ən mæt fɛlt ə tʃɪl fɹəm ɪz mədæljən. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm ʃɪvɝ əz i ɪmædʒən ðə wʌn paʊɝ likɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ ən ɪndə ðə mæn. ðət wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz daɪɪŋ, blʌɾi æʃəz bʌɾ ɪt wɑz! hi ɡɹɪp ðə mədæljən bɪniθ ɪz ʃɝt.

Edesina cut him off, rushing over and kneeling beside Delarn. She closed her eyes, and Mat felt a chill from his medallion. It made him shiver as he imagined the One Power leaking out of her and into the man. That was almost as bad as dying, bloody ashes but it was! He gripped the medallion beneath his shirt.

dɛlɑɹn stɪfənd, bʌt ðən ɡæspt, aɪz flʌɾɝɪŋ oʊpən.

Delarn stiffened, but then gasped, eyes fluttering open.

"ɪɾ ɪz dʌn," idɛzinə sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp. "hi wɪl bi wik fɹəm ðə hilɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ ɹitʃt ɪm ɪn taɪm."

"It is done," Edesina said, standing up. "He will be weak from the Healing, but I reached him in time."

hɑɹnən hæd ɡæðɝɾ ən sæɾəld ɔl ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, laɪt blɛs hɪm. ɡʊd mæn. ðə wɪmən maʊntəd, ən spɛɹd sɛvɹəl ɡlænsɪz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ət ði ɪn.

Harnan had gathered and saddled all of their horses, Light bless him. Good man. The women mounted, and spared several glances over their shoulders at the inn.

"ɪts əz ɪf ðə dɑɹknəs ɪtsɛlf ɪntɑksəkeɪts ðɛm," tɑm sɛd waɪl mæt hɛlp dɛlɑɹn ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl. "æz ɪf laɪɾ ɪtsɛlf əz fɔɹseɪkən ðɛm, livɪŋ əm oʊnli tə ðə ʃædoʊ. . . ."

"It's as if the darkness itself intoxicates them," Thom said while Mat helped Delarn into his saddle. "As if Light itself has forsaken them, leaving them only to the Shadow. . . ."

"nʌθɪŋ wi kən du," mæt sɛd, pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl bɪhaɪn dɛlɑɹn. ðə soʊlʒɝ wɑz tu wik tə ɹaɪɾ ɑn ɪz oʊn, æftɝ ðət hilɪŋ. mæt aɪd ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz ðət ðə wɔɹɾɝz hæd slʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə fɹʌns ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ðeɪ stʃɹʌɡəld əɡɛns ðɛɹ bɑnz, heɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. hi tɝn ən nɑɾəd tə tælmɑnz, hu hæɾ əfɪks ðə læntɝn tə ə sæɾəl poʊl. ðə kɛɹhinɪn oʊpən ðə ʃild, beɪðɪŋ ði ɪnz steɪbliɑɹɾ ɪn laɪt. ə pæθ lɛd nɔɹθwɝd, aʊɾ ə ðə jɑɹɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk. əweɪ fɹəm ði ɑɹmi, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ dɝɛkli aʊɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ, təwɔɹd ðə hɪlz. ðət wɑz ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ mæt.

"Nothing we can do," Mat said, pulling himself into his saddle behind Delarn. The soldier was too weak to ride on his own, after that Healing. Mat eyed the serving girls that the Warders had slung over the fronts of their horses. They struggled against their bonds, hate in their eyes. He turned and nodded to Talmanes, who had affixed the lantern to a saddle pole. The Cairhienin opened the shield, bathing the inn's stableyard in light. A path led northward, out of the yard into the dark. Away from the army, but also directly out of the village, toward the hills. That was good enough for Mat.

"ɹaɪd," hi sɛd, kɪkɪŋ pɪps ɪndə moʊʃən. ðə ɡɹup fɛl ɪn bɪsaɪd hɪm.

"Ride," he said, kicking Pips into motion. The group fell in beside him.

"aɪ toʊl jə wi ʃəd liv," tælmɑnz noʊɾəd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ət mæts lɛft.

"I told you we should leave," Talmanes noted, looking over his shoulder, riding at Mat's left.

"bʌt jə hæd tə steɪ fəɹ wʌn mɔɹ tɔs."

"But you had to stay for one more toss."

mæt dɪdn lʊk bæk. "nɑt maɪ fɔlt, tælmɑnz. haʊ wɑz aɪ tə noʊ ðət steɪɪŋ wəd kɑz əm ɔl tə stɑɹt tɛɹɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝz θɹoʊts aʊt?"

Mat didn't look back. "Not my fault, Talmanes. How was I to know that staying would cause them all to start tearing each other's throats out?"

"wʌt?" tælmɑnz æskt, ɡlænsɪŋ ət hɪm. "ɪzən ðɪs juʒəwəli haʊ pipəl ɹiækt wən jə tɛl əm jəɹ gɑnə spɛn ðə naɪt?"

"What?" Talmanes asked, glancing at him. "Isn't this usually how people react when you tell them you're going to spend the night?"

mæt ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz, bʌt dɪdn fil mʌtʃ laɪk læfɪŋ əz i lɛd ðə ɡɹup aʊɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ.

Mat rolled his eyes, but didn't feel much like laughing as he led the group out of the village.

aʊɝz leɪɾɝ, mæt sæɾ ɑn ə ɹɑk aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ ɑn ə dɑɹk hɪlsaɪd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət hɪndɝstæp. ðə vɪlədʒ wɑz dɑɹk. nɑɾ ə laɪt bɝnd. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə tɛl wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, bʌt stɪl i wɑtʃt. haʊ kəɾ ə mæn slip, æftɝ wʌt ðeɪd bɪn θɹu?

Hours later, Mat sat on a rock outcropping on a dark hillside, looking down at Hinderstap. The village was dark. Not a light burned. It was impossible to tell what was going on, but still he watched. How could a man sleep, after what they'd been through?

wɛl, ðə soʊlʒɝz dɪd slip. hi dɪdn bleɪm dɛlɑɹn. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hilɪŋ kəd dʒɹeɪn ə mæn.

Well, the soldiers did sleep. He didn't blame Delarn. An Aes Sedai Healing could drain a man.

mæt hæd fɛl ðəɾ aɪsi tʃɪl hɪmsɛlf ɑn əkeɪʒən, ən i dɪdn ɪntɛn tə ɹɪpit ði ɪkspɪɹiəns.

Mat had felt that icy chill himself on occasion, and he didn't intend to repeat the experience.

tælmɑnz ən ði ʌðɝ ɹɛdʒɹmz hædn ði ɪkskjus ʌv ə hilɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ soʊlʒɝz. soʊlʒɝz lɝn tə slip wən ðeɪ kʊd, ən ðə naɪts ɪkspɪɹiəns dɪdn sim tə hæv dɪstɝbd əm nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt hæd mæt. oʊ, ðeɪd bɪn wɝid waɪl ɪn ðə θɪk ʌv ɪt, bʌt naʊ ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ bæɾəl pæst. ənʌðɝ bæɾəl sɝvaɪvd. ðət hæd lɛd staʊt hɑɹnən tə dʒoʊkɪŋ ən smaɪlɪŋ əz ðeɪ bɛɾəd daʊn.

Talmanes and the other Redarms hadn't the excuse of a Healing, but they were soldiers. Soldiers learned to sleep when they could, and the night's experience didn't seem to have disturbed them nearly as much as it had Mat. Oh, they'd been worried while in the thick of it, but now it was just another battle passed. Another battle survived. That had led stout Harnan to joking and smiling as they bedded down.

nɑt mæt. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɑd ɹɔŋɡnəs əbaʊt ði ɪntaɪɝ ɪkspɪɹiəns. wɑz ðə kɝfju ɪntɛndəd tə kip ðɪs fɹəm hæpənɪŋ, sʌmhaʊ? hæd mæt, baɪ steɪɪŋ, kɑzd ɔl ə ðiz dɛθs? blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz. dɪd noʊ pleɪs ɪn ðə wɝl meɪk sɛns ɛnimɔɹ?

Not Mat. There was an odd wrongness about the entire experience. Was the curfew intended to keep this from happening, somehow? Had Mat, by staying, caused all of these deaths? Blood and bloody ashes. Did no place in the world make sense anymore?

"mæt, læd," tɑm sɛd, dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɪm, wɔkɪŋ wɪð ɪz fəmɪljɝ lɪmp. hid hæɾ ə fɹæktʃɝɾ ɑɹm, ðoʊ hi hædn mɛnʃən ɪɾ əntɪl idɛzinə hæd noʊɾəst ɪm flɪntʃɪŋ ən ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn hilɪŋ hɪm.

"Mat, lad," Thom said, joining him, walking with his familiar limp. He'd had a fractured arm, though he hadn't mentioned it until Edesina had noticed him flinching and insisted on Healing him.

"ju ʃəd slip." naʊ ðət ðə mun hæd ɹɪzən - hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ðə klaʊdz - ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf laɪt fəɹ mæt tə si tɑmz kənsɝn.

"You should sleep." Now that the moon had risen - hidden behind the clouds - there was enough light for Mat to see Thom's concern.

ðə ɡɹup hæd stɑpt ɪn ə smɔl hɑloʊ ɔf wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə tʃɹeɪl. ɪt ɡeɪv ə ɡʊd vju bæk təwɔɹd ðə vɪlədʒ, ən - mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli - ɪɾ oʊvɝlʊk ðə pæθ ðət mæt ən ði ʌðɝz hæd juz tə ɪskeɪp. ðə hɑloʊ leɪ ɑn ə stip hɪlsaɪd, ði oʊnli əpɹoʊtʃ fɹəm bɪloʊ. wʌn pɝsən ɑn wɑtʃ kəd kip ə ɡʊɾ aɪ aʊt fəɹ ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə snik ɪndə ðə kæmp.

The group had stopped in a small hollow off one side of the trail. It gave a good view back toward the village, and - more importantly - it overlooked the path that Mat and the others had used to escape. The hollow lay on a steep hillside, the only approach from below. One person on watch could keep a good eye out for anyone trying to sneak into the camp.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɛɾəd daʊn nɪɹ ðə bæk ə ðə hɑloʊ, ðoʊ mæt dɪdn θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ æktʃəli  slipɪŋ. dʒoʊlinz wɔɹɾɝz hæd θɔt tə bɹɪŋ bɛdʒɹoʊlz, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. wɔɹɾɝz wɝ laɪk ðæt. mæts mɛn oʊnli hæd ðɛɹ kloʊks, bʌt ðət hædn dɪtɝɾ əm fɹəm slipɪŋ. tælmɑnz wɑz ivən snɔɹɪŋ sɔfli, dɪspaɪt ðə spɹɪŋ tʃɪl. mæt hæd fɔɹbɪɾən ə faɪɝ. ɪt wɑzn soʊ koʊl ðət ðeɪ niɾəd wʌn, ən ɪt wəd dʒʌst sɪɡnəl ɛniwʌn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm.

The Aes Sedai had bedded down near the back of the hollow, though Mat didn't think they were actually sleeping. Joline's Warders had thought to bring bedrolls, just in case. Warders were like that. Mat's men only had their cloaks, but that hadn't deterred them from sleeping. Talmanes was even snoring softly, despite the spring chill. Mat had forbidden a fire. It wasn't so cold that they needed one, and it would just signal anyone looking for them.

"aɪm faɪn, tɑm," mæt sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ɹum ɑn ɪz ɹɑk əz ðə ɡlimən sɛɾəld daʊn. "jɔɹ ðə wʌn u ʃəd ɡɛt səm slip."

"I'm fine, Thom," Mat said, making room on his rock as the gleeman settled down. "You're the one who should get some sleep."

tɑm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wʌn naɪs θɪŋ aɪv noʊɾəst əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ oʊldɝ ɪz ðət jəɹ bɑɾi dʌzn sim tə niɾ ɪts slip əz mʌtʃ ɛnimɔɹ. daɪɪŋ dʌzn teɪk əz mʌtʃ ɛnɝdʒi əz ɡɹoʊɪŋ, aɪ ɡɛs."

Thom shook his head. "One nice thing I've noticed about getting older is that your body doesn't seem to need its sleep as much anymore. Dying doesn't take as much energy as growing, I guess."

"doʊn stɑɹt ðəɾ əɡɛn," mæt sɛd. "du aɪ nid tə ɹimaɪn jə əbaʊt haʊ jə hɔl maɪ skɪni bæksaɪɾ aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl bæk ðɛɹ? wʌt wɑz ðət jə wɝ wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɝliɝ? ðəɾ aɪ dɪdnt nid jə ɛnimɔɹ? ɪf jə hædn bɪn wɪð mi tədeɪ, ɪf jə hædn kʌm lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi, aɪd bi dɛɾ ɪn ðət vɪlədʒ. dɛlɑɹn tu."

"Don't start that again," Mat said. "Do I need to remind you about how you hauled my skinny backside out of trouble back there? What was that you were worried about earlier? That I didn't need you anymore? If you hadn't been with me today, if you hadn't come looking for me, I'd be dead in that village. Delarn too."

tɑm ɡɹɪnd, aɪz bɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə munlaɪt. "ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt," hi sɛd. "noʊ mɔɹ. aɪ pɹɑməs."

Thom grinned, eyes bright in the moonlight. "All right, Mat," he said. "No more. I promise."

mæt nɑɾəd. ðə tu ʌv əm sæt fəɹ ə taɪm ɑn ðɛɹ ɹɑk, lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ət ðə sɪɾi. "ɪts nɑt gɑnə liv mi əloʊn, tɑm," mæt faɪnəli sɛd.

Mat nodded. The two of them sat for a time on their rock, looking out at the city. "It's not going to leave me alone, Thom," Mat finally said.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"ɔl ə ðɪs," mæt sɛd taɪɹədli. "ðə blʌɾi dɑɹk wʌn ən ɪz spɑn. ðeɪv bɪn tʃeɪsɪŋ mi sɪns ðət naɪɾ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən nʌθɪŋ əz stɑp ðɛm."

"All of this," Mat said tiredly. "The bloody Dark One and his spawn. They've been chasing me since that night in the Two Rivers, and nothing has stopped them."

"ju θɪŋk ðɪs wɑz hɪm?"

"You think this was him?"

"wʌɾ ɛls kəɾ ɪɾ əv bɪn?" mæt æskt. "kwaɪət vɪlədʒ foʊk, tɝnɪŋ ɪndə vaɪələn mædmən? ɪts ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn wɝk, ən jə noʊ ɪt."

"What else could it have been?" Mat asked. "Quiet village folk, turning into violent madmen? It's the Dark One's own work, and you know it."

tɑm wɑz saɪlənt. "jɛs," hi faɪnəli sɛd. "aɪ səpoʊz ɪts ət ðæt."

Thom was silent. "Yes," he finally said. "I suppose it is at that."

"ðeɪɹ stɪl kʌmɪŋ fəɹ mi," mæt sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. "ðæt blʌɾi ɡoʊləm ɪz aʊt ðɛɹ, aɪ noʊ ɪɾ ɪz, bʌt ðæts dʒʌs pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. mɹdʒɹɑl ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz, mɑnstɝz ən ɡoʊsts. tʃeɪsɪŋ mi ən hʌntɪŋ mi.

"They're still coming for me," Mat said angrily. "That bloody gholam is out there, I know it is, but that's just part of it. Myrddraal and Darkfriends, monsters and ghosts. Chasing me and hunting me.

aɪv stʌmbəl fɹəm wʌn dɪzæstɝ tə ənʌðɝ, bɛɹli kipɪŋ maɪ nɛk əbʌv wɔɾɝ, ɛvɝ sɪns ðɪs bɪɡæn. aɪ kip seɪɪŋ aɪ dʒʌs nid tə faɪn ə hoʊl sʌmwɛɹ tə daɪs ən dʒɹɪŋk, bʌt ðət woʊn stɑp ɪt.

I've stumbled from one disaster to another, barely keeping my neck above water, ever since this began. I keep saying I just need to find a hole somewhere to dice and drink, but that won't stop it.

nʌθɪŋ wɪl."

Nothing will."

"jɔɹ tɑvɝən, læd," tɑm sɛd.

"You're ta'veren, lad," Thom said.

"aɪ dɪdn æsk tə bi. bɝn mi, aɪ wɪʃ ðeɪɾ ɔl dʒʌst ɡoʊ bɑðɝ ɹænd. hi laɪks ɪt." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, dɪspɛlɪŋ ði ɪmədʒ ðət fɔɹmd, ʃoʊɪŋ ɹænd əslip ɪn ɪz bɛd, mɪn kɝld ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm.

"I didn't ask to be. Burn me, I wish they'd all just go bother Rand. He likes it." He shook his head, dispelling the image that formed, showing Rand asleep in his bed, Min curled up beside him.

"ju ɹɪli θɪŋk ðæt?" tɑm æskt.

"You really think that?" Thom asked.

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ dɪd," hi ədmɪɾəd. "ɪt wəd meɪk θɪŋz iziɝ."

Mat hesitated. "I wish I did," he admitted. "It would make things easier."

"laɪz nɛvɝ meɪk θɪŋz iziɝ ɪn ðə lɔŋ ɹʌn. ənlɛs ðəɹ tə ɪɡzækli ðə ɹaɪt pɝsən - juʒəwəli ə wʊmən - əɾ ɪɡzækli ðə ɹaɪt taɪm. wən jə tɛl əm tə jɝsɛlf, jə dʒʌs bɹɪŋ mɔɹ tʃɹʌbəl."

"Lies never make things easier in the long run. Unless they're to exactly the right person - usually a woman - at exactly the right time. When you tell them to yourself, you just bring more trouble."

"aɪ bɹɔt ðoʊz pipəl tʃɹʌbəl. ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ." hi ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə bæk ə ðə kæmp, wɛɹ ðə tu wɔɹɾɝz sæt, ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə stɪl-baʊn sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz. ðeɪ kəntɪnjud tə stʃɹʌɡəl. laɪt! wɛɹ dɪd ðeɪ ɡɛt ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ? ɪt wɑz ɪnhjumən.

"I brought those people trouble. In the village." He glanced toward the back of the camp, where the two Warders sat, guarding the still-bound serving girls. They continued to struggle. Light! Where did they get the strength? It was inhuman.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðɪs wɑz ju, mæt," tɑm sɛd θɔtfəli. "oʊ, aɪ doʊn dɪsəɡɹi ðət tʃɹʌbəl hʌns jə - ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf simz tə də soʊ. bʌt hɪndɝstæp . . . wɛl, wən aɪ wɑz sɪŋɪŋ ɪn ðət kɑmən ɹum, aɪ hɝd səm tɪdbɪts. ðeɪ sim laɪk nʌθɪŋ. bʌt lʊkɪŋ bæk, ɪt stʃɹaɪks mi ðət ðə pipəl wɝ ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðɪs. əɹ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ɪt."

"I don't think this was you, Mat," Thom said thoughtfully. "Oh, I don't disagree that trouble hunts you - the Dark One himself seems to do so. But Hinderstap . . . well, when I was singing in that common room, I heard some tidbits. They seemed like nothing. But looking back, it strikes me that the people were expecting this. Or something like it."

"haʊ kəd ðeɪv bɪn?" mæt sɛd. "ɪf ðɪs hæd hæpən bɪfɔɹ, ðeɪɾ ɔl bi dɛd."

"How could they have been?" Mat said. "If this had happened before, they'd all be dead."

"doʊnt noʊ," tɑm sɛd θɔtfəli. ðən sʌmθɪŋ sim tə stʃɹaɪk hɪm. hi bɪɡæn fɪʃɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz kloʊk. "oʊ, aɪ fɝɡɑt. meɪbi ðəɹ ɪz səm kənɛkʃən bɪtwin jə ən wʌt hæpənd. aɪ mænədʒ tə teɪk ðɪs əweɪ fɹəm ə mæn u wɑz tu dʒɹʌŋk fəɹ ɪz oʊn ɡʊd." ðə ɡlimən pʊld aʊɾ ə foʊldəd pis ə peɪpɝ ən hændəɾ ɪt tə mæt.

"Don't know," Thom said thoughtfully. Then something seemed to strike him. He began fishing inside his cloak. "Oh, I forgot. Maybe there is some connection between you and what happened. I managed to take this away from a man who was too drunk for his own good." The gleeman pulled out a folded piece of paper and handed it to Mat.

mæt tʊk ðə peɪpɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ, ən ənfoʊldəɾ ɪt. hi skwɪntɪɾ ɪn ðə dɪfjus munlaɪt, linɪŋ kloʊs, ən ɡɹʌntɪd wən i meɪɾ aʊt wʌt ðə peɪpɝ kənteɪnd - nɑt wɝdz, bʌɾ ə vɛɹi ækjɝət dʒɹɔɪŋ ə mæts feɪs, hæɾ ətɑp ɪz hɛd. ɪɾ ivən hæd ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən dʒɹɔn ɪn ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. blʌɾi æʃəz.

Mat took the paper, frowning, and unfolded it. He squinted in the diffuse moonlight, leaning close, and grunted when he made out what the paper contained - not words, but a very accurate drawing of Mat's face, hat atop his head. It even had the foxhead medallion drawn in around his neck. Bloody ashes.

hi kənteɪn ɪz ənɔɪəns. "hænsəm fɛloʊ. ɡʊd noʊz, stʃɹeɪt tiθ, dæʃɪŋ hæt."

He contained his annoyance. "Handsome fellow. Good nose, straight teeth, dashing hat."

tɑm snɔɹɾɪd.

Thom snorted.

"aɪ sɔ səm mɛn ʃoʊɪŋ ə peɪpɝ tə ðə meɪɝ," mæt sɛd, ɹifoʊldɪŋ ðə dʒɹɔɪŋ. "aɪ dɪdn si wʌt wɑz ɑn ɪt, bʌɾ əl bɛɾ ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm əz ðɪs. wʌd ðə mæn jə tʊk ðɪs fɹəm seɪ əbaʊɾ ɪt?"

"I saw some men showing a paper to the mayor," Mat said, refolding the drawing. "I didn't see what was on it, but I'll bet it was the same as this. What did the man you took this from say about it?"

"æn aʊtləndɝ wʊmən ɪn səm vɪlədʒ nɔɹθ ə hɪɹ ɪz ɡɪvɪŋ əm aʊɾ ən ɔfɝɪŋ ə ɹɪwɔɹd tə ɛniwʌn u hæz sin ju. ðə mæn ɡɑt ðə peɪpɝ fɹəm ə fɹɛnd, soʊ hi dɪdn əv ə dɪskɹɪpʃən ə hɝ əɹ ðə taʊnz neɪm. iðɝ ɪz fɹɛn kɛpt ɪm ɪɡnɝənt, wɑntɪŋ ðə ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, əɹ i wɑz dʒʌs tu dʒɹʌŋk tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ."

"An outlander woman in some village north of here is giving them out and offering a reward to anyone who has seen you. The man got the paper from a friend, so he didn't have a description of her or the town's name. Either his friend kept him ignorant, wanting the reward for himself, or he was just too drunk to remember."

mæt tʌk ðə peɪpɝ ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkət. ðə laɪɾ ə fɔls dɔn wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɡloʊ tə ði ist. hid sæɾ ʌp ɔl naɪt, bʌɾ i dɪdn fil taɪɝd. dʒʌst . . . dʒɹeɪnd. "aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ bæk," hi sɛd.

Mat tucked the paper into his coat pocket. The light of false dawn was beginning to glow to the east. He'd sat up all night, but he didn't feel tired. Just . . . drained. "I'm going back," he said.

"wʌt?" tɑm æskt, sɝpɹaɪzd. "tə hɪndɝstæp?"

"What?" Thom asked, surprised. "To Hinderstap?"

mæt nɑɾəd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. "æz sun əz ɪts laɪt. aɪ nid tə - "

Mat nodded, rising. "As soon as it's light. I need to - "

ə mʌfəl kɝs ɪntɝʌptɪd hɪm. hi spʌn, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ. tɑm hæɾ ə pɛɹ ə naɪvz ɪn ɪz hænz ɪn ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ. fɛn, dʒoʊlinz sɑldəiən wɔɹɾɝ, wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd kɝst. hi stʊd, hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd, sɝtʃɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn hɪm. blɹɪk stʊd baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, sɔɹɾ aʊt, əlɝɾ ən ɑn ɡɑɹd.

A muffled curse interrupted him. He spun, reaching for his ashandarei. Thom had a pair of knives in his hands in the blink of an eye. Fen, Joline's Saldaean Warder, was the one who had cursed. He stood, hand on his sword, searching the ground around him. Blaeric stood by the Aes Sedai, sword out, alert and on guard.

"wʌt?" mæt æsk tɝsli.

"What?" Mat asked tersely.

"ðə pɹɪznɝz," fɛn sɛd.

"The prisoners," Fen said.

mæt stɑɹɾəd, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ðə lʌmps ðət hæd leɪn nɪɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝz wɝ ɡɔn. hi dæʃt oʊvɝ, kɝsɪŋ. tælmɑnz' snɔɹz stɑpt əz ðə saʊnz woʊk ɪm ən i sæɾ ʌp. ðə bɑnz meɪd fɹəm stʃɹɪps ə dʒoʊlinz dʒɹɛs leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌt ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz wɝ ɡɔn.

Mat started, realizing that the lumps that had lain near the Warders were gone. He dashed over, cursing. Talmanes' snores stopped as the sounds woke him and he sat up. The bonds made from strips of Joline's dress lay on the ground, but the serving girls were gone.

"wʌt hæpənd?" mæt æskt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp.

"What happened?" Mat asked, looking up.

"aɪ . . ." ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹd wɔɹɾɝ lʊk dʌmfaʊndɪd. "aɪ hæv noʊ aɪdiə. ðeɪ wɝ hɪɹ dʒʌst ə moʊmən əɡoʊ!"

"I . . ." The dark-haired Warder looked dumbfounded. "I have no idea. They were here just a moment ago!"

"dɪd jə doʊz ɔf?" mæt dɪmændəd.

"Did you doze off?" Mat demanded.

"fɛn wʊdn əv dʌn sətʃ ə θɪŋ," dʒoʊlin sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp ɪn əɹ bɛdʒɹoʊl, hɝ vɔɪs kɑm. ʃi stɪl wɔɹ oʊnli ðət dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹoʊb.

"Fen wouldn't have done such a thing," Joline said, sitting up in her bedroll, her voice calm. She still wore only that dressing robe.

"læd," tɑm sɛd, "wi boʊθ sɔ ðoʊz ɡɝlz hɪɹ bɛɹli ə mɪnəɾ əɡoʊ."

"Lad," Thom said, "we both saw those girls here barely a minute ago."

tælmɑnz kɝst ən woʊk ðə faɪv ɹɛdʒɹmz. dɛlɑɹn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt dil bɛɾɝ, hɪz wiknəs fɹəm ðə hilɪŋ bɛɹli simɪŋ tə bɑðɝ ɪm əz i klaɪm tə hɪz fit. ðə wɔɹɾɝz kɔl fəɹ ə sɝtʃ, bʌt mæt dʒʌs tɝn bæk tə ðə vɪlədʒ bɪloʊ. "ði ænsɝz ɑɹ ðɛɹ," mæt sɛd.

Talmanes cursed and woke the five Redarms. Delarn was looking a great deal better, his weakness from the Healing barely seeming to bother him as he climbed to his feet. The Warders called for a search, but Mat just turned back to the village below. "The answers are there," Mat said.

"tɑm, jəɹ wɪð mi. tælmɑnz, wɑtʃ ðə wɪmən."

"Thom, you're with me. Talmanes, watch the women."

"wi hæv lɪɾəl niɾ ə biɪŋ 'wɑtʃt,' meɪtʃɹim," dʒoʊlin sɛd ɡɹʌmpəli.

"We have little need of being 'watched,' Matrim," Joline said grumpily.

"faɪn," hi snæpt. "tɑm, jəɹ wɪð mi. dʒoʊlin, jə wɑtʃ ðə soʊlʒɝz. iðɝ weɪ, jə ɔl steɪ hɪɹ. aɪ kænt wɝi əbaʊɾ ə hoʊl ɡɹup ɹaɪt naʊ."

"Fine," he snapped. "Thom, you're with me. Joline, you watch the soldiers. Either way, you all stay here. I can't worry about a whole group right now."

hi dɪdnt ɡɪv əm ə tʃæns tə ɑɹɡju. wɪðɪn mɪnəts, mæt ən tɑm wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə pæθ bæk təwɔɹd hɪndɝstæp.

He didn't give them a chance to argue. Within minutes, Mat and Thom were on their horses, riding down the path back toward Hinderstap.

"læd," tɑm sɛd, "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə ɪkspɛk tə faɪnd?"

"Lad," Thom said, "what is it you expect to find?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," mæt ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪf aɪ dɪd, aɪ wʊdn bi soʊ kin tə lʊk."

"I don't know," Mat replied. "If I did, I wouldn't be so keen to look."

"fɛɹ ɪnʌf," tɑm sɛd sɔfli.

"Fair enough," Thom said softly.

mæt spɑɾəd ði ɑɾətiz ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli. ðoʊz ɡoʊts aʊɾ ɑn ðə wɛstɝn pæstʃɝ. hi kʊdn tɛl fəɹ sɝɾən ɪn ðə dɔn laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt lʊk laɪk sʌmwʌn wɑz hɝɾɪŋ ðɛm. ən wɝ ðoʊz laɪts wɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ? ðəɹ hædn bɪn ə sɪŋɡəl wʌn ə ðoʊz ɔl naɪt lɔŋ! hi heɪsən pɪps'

Mat spotted the oddities almost immediately. Those goats out on the western pasture. He couldn't tell for certain in the dawn light, but it looked like someone was herding them. And were those lights winking on in the village? There hadn't been a single one of those all night long! He hastened Pips'

peɪs, tɑm fɑloʊɪŋ saɪlənli.

pace, Thom following silently.

ɪt tʊk ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ən aʊɝ tə ɝaɪv - mæt hædnt wɑntəd tə ɹɪsk kæmpɪŋ tu kloʊs, ðoʊ hiɾ ɔlsoʊ bɪn dɪsɪnklaɪn tə hʌn ə weɪ ɝaʊn ən bæk tə ði ɑɹmi ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ɪt wɑz fʊli laɪt, ɪf stɪl vɛɹi ɝli, baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹoʊd bæk ɪndə ði ɪnz jɑɹd. ə kʌpəl ə mɛn ɪn dʌn koʊts wɝ wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðə bæk dɔɹ, wɪtʃ hæɾ əpɛɹənli bɪn bɹoʊkən ɔf ɪts hɪnʒɪz sʌmtaɪm æftɝ mæt ən ði ʌðɝz lɛft. ðə mɛn lʊkt ʌp əz mæt ən tɑm ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə jɑɹd, ən wʌn ə ðɛm pʊld ɔf ɪz kæp, lʊkɪŋ æŋkʃəs. niðɝ wʌn meɪɾ ə θɹɛɾənɪŋ muv.

It took the better part of an hour to arrive - Mat hadn't wanted to risk camping too close, though he'd also been disinclined to hunt a way around and back to the army in the dark. It was fully light, if still very early, by the time they rode back into the inn's yard. A couple of men in dun coats were working on the back door, which had apparently been broken off its hinges sometime after Mat and the others left. The men looked up as Mat and Thom rode into the yard, and one of them pulled off his cap, looking anxious. Neither one made a threatening move.

mæt sloʊd pɪps tə ə hɔlt. wʌn ə ðə mɛn wɪspɝd tə ði ʌðɝ, hu ɹæn ɪnsaɪd. ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, ə bɔldɪŋ mæn wɪð ə waɪɾ eɪpɹən stɛpt aʊt θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ. mæt fɛl hɪmsɛlf ɡoʊ peɪl.

Mat slowed Pips to a halt. One of the men whispered to the other, who ran inside. A moment later, a balding man with a white apron stepped out through the doorway. Mat felt himself go pale.

"ði ɪnkipɝ," mæt sɛd. "bɝn mi, aɪ sɔ jə dɛd!"

"The innkeeper," Mat said. "Burn me, I saw you dead!"

"bɛst ɡoʊ ɡɛt ðə meɪɝ, sʌn," ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd tə wʌn ə ðə wɝkɪŋ mɛn. hi ɡlæns bæk ət mæt. "kwɪkli. "

"Best go get the mayor, son," the innkeeper said to one of the working men. He glanced back at Mat. "Quickly. "

"wʌɾ ɪn ðə blʌɾi neɪm ə hɔkwɪŋz lɛf hæn ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn hɪɹ?" mæt dɪmændəd. "wɑz ɪɾ ɔl səm kaɪndə twɪstəd ʃoʊ? jə - "

"What in the bloody name of Hawkwing's left hand is going on here?" Mat demanded. "Was it all some kind of twisted show? You - "

ə hɛd stʌk aʊɾ ə ði ɪn dɔɹ, pikɪŋ ɝaʊn ði ɪnkipɝ təwɔɹd mæt. ðə pʌdʒi feɪs hæd kɝli blɑn hɛɹ. læs taɪm hid sin ðɪs mæn, ðə kʊk, mæt hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə ɡʌt ðə mæn ən slɪɾ ɪz θɹoʊt.

A head stuck out of the inn door, peeking around the innkeeper toward Mat. The pudgy face had curly blond hair. Last time he'd seen this man, the cook, Mat had been forced to gut the man and slit his throat.

"ju!" hi sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ. "aɪ kɪl ju!"

"You!" he said, pointing. "I killed you!"

"kɑm daʊn, naʊ, sʌn," ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd. "kʌm ɪn, wɪl ɡɛt jə səm ti, ən - "

"Calm down, now, son," the innkeeper said. "Come in, we'll get you some tea, and - "

"aɪm nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ wɪð ju, spɪɹət," mæt sɛd. "tɑm, jə siɪŋ ðɪs?"

"I'm not going anywhere with you, spirit," Mat said. "Thom, you seeing this?"

ðə ɡlimən ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn. "pɝhæps wi ʃəd hɪɹ ðə mæn aʊt, mæt."

The gleeman rubbed his chin. "Perhaps we should hear the man out, Mat."

"ɡoʊsts ən spɪɹəts," mæt mʌɾɝd, tɝnɪŋ pɪps. "kʌm ɑn." hi ɝdʒ pɪps fɔɹwɝd, tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ɝaʊn tə ðə fɹʌn ə ði ɪn, tɑm fɑloʊɪŋ. hɪɹ i kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə mɛni wɝkɝz ɪnsaɪd, kæɹiɪŋ bʌkəts ʌv waɪt peɪnt. tə fɪks ðə pleɪsəz wɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ faɪɝ hæd skɔɹd ðə bɪldɪŋ, laɪkli.

"Ghosts and spirits," Mat muttered, turning Pips. "Come on." He urged Pips forward, charging around to the front of the inn, Thom following. Here he caught a glimpse of many workers inside, carrying buckets of white paint. To fix the places where Aes Sedai fire had scored the building, likely.

tɑm pʊld ʌp bɪsaɪd mæt. "aɪv nɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs, mæt," hi sɛd. "waɪ wəd spɪɹəts nid tə peɪnt wɔlz ən ɹɪpɛɹ dɔɹz?"

Thom pulled up beside Mat. "I've never seen anything like this, Mat," he said. "Why would spirits need to paint walls and repair doors?"

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hid spɑɾəd ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hid fɔt ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz tə seɪv dɛlɑɹn. hi pʊl pɪps tə ə hɔl sʌɾənli, meɪkɪŋ tɑm kɝs ən ɹaʊn ɪz oʊn maʊn ɝaʊn tə kʌm bæk.

Mat shook his head. He'd spotted the place where he'd fought the villagers to save Delarn. He pulled Pips to a halt suddenly, making Thom curse and round his own mount around to come back.

"wʌt?" tɑm æskt.

"What?" Thom asked.

mæt pɔɪntəd. ðəɹ wɑz ə steɪn ə blʌɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ən əkɹɔs sɛvɹəl ɹɑks bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd.

Mat pointed. There was a stain of blood on the ground and across several rocks beside the road.

"wɛɹ ðeɪ stæb dɛlɑɹn," hi sɛd.

"Where they stabbed Delarn," he said.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," tɑm sɛd. ɝaʊn ðɛm, mɛn pæst ɑn ðə stʃɹit, ɡeɪzəz əvɝɾəd. ðeɪ ɡeɪv mæt ən tɑm ə waɪd bɝθ.

"All right," Thom said. Around them, men passed on the street, gazes averted. They gave Mat and Thom a wide berth.

blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz, mæt θɔt. aɪv ɡɑɾən əs sɝaʊndəɾ əɡɛn. wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ ətæk?

Blood and bloody ashes, Mat thought. I've gotten us surrounded again. What if they attack?

blʌɾi ful!

Bloody fool!

"soʊ ðɛɹz blʌd," tɑm sɛd. "wʌt dɪd jə ɪkspɛkt?"

"So there's blood," Thom said. "What did you expect?"

"wɛɹz ðə ɹɛst ə ðə blʌd, tɑm?" mæt ɡɹaʊld. "aɪ kɪld ə ɡʊd dʌzən mɛn hɪɹ, ən aɪ sɔ ðɛm blid. jə dʒɹɑp θɹi wɪð jəɹ naɪvz. wɛɹz ðə blʌd?"

"Where's the rest of the blood, Thom?" Mat growled. "I killed a good dozen men here, and I saw them bleed. You dropped three with your knives. Where's the blood?"

"ɪt vænɪʃɪz," ə vɔɪs sɛd.

"It vanishes," a voice said.

mæt spʌn pɪps tə faɪn ðə bɝli, hɛɹi-ɑɹmd meɪɝ stændɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹoʊɾ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ. hi mʌst əv bɪn nɪɹ ɔlɹɛɾi; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ ðə wɝkɝz cʊɾə fɛtʃt ɪm ðət kwɪkli. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə weɪ θɪŋz sim tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn ðɪs vɪlədʒ, hu kəd tɛl ðət fəɹ sɝɾən? bɑɹldən wɔɹ ə kloʊk ən ʃɝt wɪð sɛvɹəl fɹɛʃ ɹɪps ɪn ðɛm.

Mat spun Pips to find the burly, hairy-armed mayor standing on the road a short distance away. He must have been near already; there was no way the workers could have fetched him that quickly. Of course, the way things seemed to be going in this village, who could tell that for certain? Barlden wore a cloak and shirt with several fresh rips in them.

"ðə blʌd vænɪʃɪz," hi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɪɡzɔstəd. "nʌn ʌv əs əv sin ɪt. wi dʒʌst weɪk ʌp ən ɪts ɡɔn."

"The blood vanishes," he said, sounding exhausted. "None of us have seen it. We just wake up and it's gone."

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə vɪlədʒ. wɪmən pikt aʊɾ ə haʊsəz, hoʊldɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən. mɛn lɛft fəɹ ðə filz, kæɹiɪŋ kɹʊks əɹ hoʊz. seɪv fəɹ ði ɛɹ ʌv æŋzaɪəɾi ət mæt ən tɑmz pɹɛzəns, wʌn wəd nɛvɝ noʊ ɛniθɪŋ hæd ɡɔn ɹɔŋ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ.

Mat hesitated, looking around the village. Women peeked out of houses, holding children. Men left for the fields, carrying crooks or hoes. Save for the air of anxiety at Mat and Thom's presence, one would never know anything had gone wrong in the village.

"wi woʊn hɝt ju," ðə meɪɝ sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm mæt. "soʊ jə nidn lʊk soʊ wɝid.

"We won't hurt you," the mayor said, turning away from Mat. "So you needn't look so worried.

ət list, nɑɾ əntɪl ðə sʌn sɛts. əl ɡɪv jə ən ɛkspləneɪʃən, ɪf jə wɑnt wʌn. iðɝ kʌm ən lɪsən əɹ bi ɡɔn wɪð ju. aɪ doʊn ɹɪli kɛɹ, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə stɑp dɪstɝbɪŋ maɪ taʊn. wiv wɝk tə du.

At least, not until the sun sets. I'll give you an explanation, if you want one. Either come and listen or be gone with you. I don't really care, so long as you stop disturbing my town. We've work to do.

mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən juʒəwəl, θæŋks tə ju."

Much more than usual, thanks to you."

mæt ɡlænst ət tɑm, hu ʃɹʌɡd. "ɪt nɛvɝ hɝts tə lɪsən," tɑm sɛd.

Mat glanced at Thom, who shrugged. "It never hurts to listen," Thom said.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," mæt sɛd, aɪɪŋ bɑɹldən. "nɑɾ ənlɛs jə θɪŋk ɪt kəd hɝt tə ɛn ʌp sɝaʊndəd baɪ kɹeɪzi, hɑməsaɪɾəl maʊnteɪaɪnfoʊk."

"I don't know," Mat said, eyeing Barlden. "Not unless you think it could hurt to end up surrounded by crazy, homicidal mountainfolk."

"wi liv, ðɛn?"

"We leave, then?"

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sloʊli. "noʊ. bɝn mi, ðeɪv stɪl ɡɑt maɪ ɡoʊld. kʌm ɑn, lɛts si wʌt hiz tə seɪ."

Mat shook his head slowly. "No. Burn me, they've still got my gold. Come on, let's see what he has to say."

"ɪt stɑɹɾəd sɛvɹəl mʌnθs bæk," ðə meɪɝ sɛd, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊ. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ə nit  - jɛt sɪmpəl - sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ɪn ɪz mænɝ. ðə kɝɾənz ən kɑɹpət wɝ ʌv ə sɑf peɪl ɡɹin, ɔlmoʊs ðə kʌlɝ ʌv ɑksiaɪ livz, wɪð laɪt tæn wʊd pænəlɪŋ. ðə meɪɝz waɪf hæd bɹɔt ti meɪd fɹəm dʒɹaɪd switbɛɹiz. mæt hædn tʃoʊzən tə dʒɹɪŋk ɛni, ən i hæd meɪd sɝɾən tə lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl nɪɹ ðə stʃɹit dɔɹ. hɪz spɪɹ ɹɛstəd bɪsaɪd hɪm.

"It started several months back," the mayor said, standing beside the window. They were in a neat  - yet simple - sitting room in his manor. The curtains and carpet were of a soft pale green, almost the color of oxeye leaves, with light tan wood paneling. The mayor's wife had brought tea made from dried sweetberries. Mat hadn't chosen to drink any, and he had made certain to lean against the wall near the street door. His spear rested beside him.

bɑɹldənz waɪf wɑz ə ʃɔɹt, bɹaʊn-hɛɹd wʊmən, feɪnli pʌdʒi, wɪð ə mʌðɝli ɛɹ. ʃi ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðə kɪtʃən, kæɹiɪŋ ə boʊl ə hʌni fəɹ ðə ti, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz ʃi sɔ mæt linɪŋ baɪ ðə wɔl. ʃi aɪd ðə spɪɹ, ðən pʊt ðə boʊl ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən ɹitʃɹiɾəd.

Barlden's wife was a short, brown-haired woman, faintly pudgy, with a motherly air. She returned from the kitchen, carrying a bowl of honey for the tea, then hesitated as she saw Mat leaning by the wall. She eyed the spear, then put the bowl on the table and retreated.

"wʌt hæpənd?" mæt æskt, ɡlænsɪŋ ət tɑm, hu hæɾ ɔlsoʊ dɪklaɪn ə sit. ði oʊld ɡlimən stʊd wɪð ɑɹmz kɹɔs bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz. hi nɑɾəd tə mæt; ðə wʊmən wɑzn lɪsnɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ. hid meɪk ə moʊʃən ɪf i hɝd sʌmwʌn əpɹoʊtʃ.

"What happened?" Mat asked, glancing at Thom, who had also declined a seat. The old gleeman stood with arms crossed beside the door from the kitchens. He nodded to Mat; the woman wasn't listening at the door. He'd make a motion if he heard someone approach.

"wi ɑɹənt ʃʊɹ ɪf ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ wi dɪd, əɹ dʒʌst ə kɹuəl kɝs baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf," ðə meɪɝ sɛd. "ɪt wɑz ə nɔɹməl deɪ, ɝli ðɪs jɪɹ, dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə fist ʌv əbɹæm. nʌθɪŋ ɹɪli spɛʃəl əbaʊɾ ɪt ðəɾ aɪ kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ðə wɛðɝ hæd bɹoʊkən baɪ ðɛn, ðoʊ ðə snoʊz hædn kʌm jɛt. ə lɑɾ ʌv əs wɛn əbaʊɾ əɹ nɔɹməl æktɪvəɾiz ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ, θɪŋkɪŋ nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɪt.

"We aren't sure if it was something we did, or just a cruel curse by the Dark One himself," the mayor said. "It was a normal day, early this year, just before the Feast of Abram. Nothing really special about it that I can remember. The weather had broken by then, though the snows hadn't come yet. A lot of us went about our normal activities the next morning, thinking nothing of it.

"ði ɑɾətiz wɝ smɔl, jə si. ə bɹoʊkən dɔɹ hɪɹ, ə ɹɪp ɪn sʌmwʌnz kloʊðɪŋ ðeɪ dɪdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ən ðə naɪtmɛɹz. wi ɔl ʃɛɹd ðɛm, naɪtmɛɹz ə dɛθ ən kɪlɪŋ. ə fju ʌv ðə wɪmən stɑɹɾəd tɔkɪŋ, ən ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðət ðeɪ kʊdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ tɝnɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹiviəs ivnɪŋ.

"The oddities were small, you see. A broken door here, a rip in someone's clothing they didn't remember. And the nightmares. We all shared them, nightmares of death and killing. A few of the women started talking, and they realized that they couldn't remember turning in the previous evening.

ðeɪ kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ weɪkɪŋ, seɪf ən kʌmftəɹbəl ɪn ðɛɹ bɛdz, bʌɾ oʊnli ə fju ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ æktʃəli  ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪndə bɛd. ðoʊz u kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ hæd ɡɔn tə slip ɝli, bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs, ðə leɪɾ ivnɪŋ wɑz dʒʌst ə blɝ."

They could remember waking, safe and comfortable in their beds, but only a few remembered actually getting into bed. Those who could remember had gone to sleep early, before sunset. For the rest of us, the late evening was just a blur."

hi fɛl saɪlənt. mæt ɡlænst ət tɑm, hu dɪd nɑt ɹɪspɑnd. mæt kəd si ɪn ðoʊz blu aɪz ə hɪz ðəɾ i wɑz mɛmɝaɪzɪŋ ðə teɪl. hid bɛɾɝ ɡɛɾ ɪt ɹaɪɾ ɪf i pʊts mi ɪn ɛni bælədz, mæt θɔt, foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz. ən hid bɛɾɝ ɪnklud maɪ hæt. ðɪs ɪz ə ɡʊd blʌɾi hæt.

He fell silent. Mat glanced at Thom, who did not respond. Mat could see in those blue eyes of his that he was memorizing the tale. He'd better get it right if he puts me in any ballads, Mat thought, folding his arms. And he'd better include my hat. This is a good bloody hat.

"aɪ wɑz ɪn ðə pæstʃɝz ðət naɪt," ðə meɪɝ kəntɪnjud. "aɪ wɑz hɛlpɪŋ oʊl mæn ɡɑɹkən wɪð ə bɹoʊkən stʃɹɪp ə fɛnsɪŋ. ən ðən . . . nʌθɪŋ. ə fʌzɪŋ. aɪ əwoʊk ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ ɪn maɪ oʊn bɛd, nɛks tə maɪ waɪf. wi fɛl taɪɝd, əz ɪf wi hædn slɛpt wɛl." hi stɑpt, ðən mɔɹ sɔfli, hi æɾəd, "æn aɪ hæd ðə naɪtmɛɹz. ðəɹ veɪɡ, ən ðeɪ feɪd. bʌɾ aɪ kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌn vɪvəɾ ɪmədʒ. oʊl mæn ɡɑɹkən, dɛɾ ət maɪ fit. kɪld əz ɪf baɪ ə waɪl bist."

"I was in the pastures that night," the mayor continued. "I was helping old man Garken with a broken strip of fencing. And then . . . nothing. A fuzzing. I awoke the next morning in my own bed, next to my wife. We felt tired, as if we hadn't slept well." He stopped, then more softly, he added, "And I had the nightmares. They're vague, and they fade. But I can remember one vivid image. Old man Garken, dead at my feet. Killed as if by a wild beast."

bɑɹldən stʊd nɛks tə ə wɪndoʊ ɪn ði istɝn wɔl, ɑpəzət mæt, stɛɹɪŋ aʊt. "bʌɾ aɪ wɛn tə si ɡɑɹkən ðə nɛks deɪ, ən i wɑz faɪn. wi fɪnɪʃt fɪksɪŋ ðə fɛns. ɪt wɑzn əntɪl aɪ ɡɑt bæk tə taʊn ðəɾ aɪ hɝd ðə tʃæɾɝɪŋ. ðə ʃɛɹd naɪtmɛɹz, ðə mɪsɪŋ aʊɝz dʒʌst æftɝ sʌnsɛt. wi ɡæðɝd, tɔkɪŋ ɪt θɹu, ən ðən ɪt hæpən əɡɛn. ðə sʌn sɛt, ən wən ɪt ɹoʊz aɪ woʊk ʌp ɪn bɛɾ əɡɛn, taɪɝd, maɪn fʊl ə naɪtmɛɹz." hi ʃɪvɝd, ðən wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ðə teɪbəl ən pɔɹd hɪmsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti.

Barlden stood next to a window in the eastern wall, opposite Mat, staring out. "But I went to see Garken the next day, and he was fine. We finished fixing the fence. It wasn't until I got back to town that I heard the chattering. The shared nightmares, the missing hours just after sunset. We gathered, talking it through, and then it happened again. The sun set, and when it rose I woke up in bed again, tired, mind full of nightmares." He shivered, then walked over to the table and poured himself a cup of tea.

"wi doʊnt noʊ wʌt hæpənz ət naɪt," ðə meɪɝ sɛd, stɝɪŋ ɪn ə spunfʊl ə hʌni.

"We don't know what happens at night," the mayor said, stirring in a spoonful of honey.

"ju doʊnt noʊ?" mæt dɪmændəd. "aɪ kən blʌɾi tɛl jə wʌt hæpənz ət naɪt. jə - "

"You don't know?" Mat demanded. "I can bloody tell you what happens at night. You - "

"wi doʊnt noʊ wʌt hæpənz," ðə meɪɝ ɪntɝʌptɪd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ʃɑɹpli. "æn əv noʊ kɛɹ tə noʊ."

"We don't know what happens," the mayor interrupted, looking up sharply. "And have no care to know."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"wi hæv noʊ nid tə noʊ, aʊtləndɝ," ðə meɪɝ sɛd hɑɹʃli. "wi wɑnə lɪv əɹ laɪvz əz bɛst wi kæn. mɛni ʌv əs tɝn ɪn ɝli, laɪɪŋ daʊn bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt. ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ hoʊlz ɪn əɹ mɛmɹiz ðət weɪ. wi ɡoʊ tə bɛd, wi weɪk ʌp ɪn ðət seɪm bɛd. ðəɹ ɑɹ naɪtmɛɹz, pɝhæps səm dæmədʒ tə ðə haʊs, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ðət kæn bi fɪkst. ʌðɝz pɹəfɝ tə vɪzəɾ ə tævɝn ən dʒɹɪŋk tə ðə sɛɾɪŋ ə ðə sʌn.

"We have no need to know, outlander," the mayor said harshly. "We want to live our lives as best we can. Many of us turn in early, lying down before sunset. There are no holes in our memories that way. We go to bed, we wake up in that same bed. There are nightmares, perhaps some damage to the house, but nothing that can't be fixed. Others prefer to visit a tavern and drink to the setting of the sun.

ðɛɹz ə blɛsɪŋ ɪn ðæt, aɪ səpoʊz. dʒɹɪŋk ɔl jə wɑnt, ən jə nɛvɝ əv tə wɝi əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ hoʊm. jə ɔlweɪz weɪk seɪf ən saʊn ɪn bɛd."

There's a blessing in that, I suppose. Drink all you want, and you never have to worry about getting home. You always wake safe and sound in bed."

"ju kæn əvɔɪd ðɪs ɪntaɪɝli," tɑm sɛd sɔfli. "ju kæn pɹitɛnd nʌθɪŋ ɪz dɪfɹənt."

"You can't avoid this entirely," Thom said softly. "You can't pretend nothing is different."

"wi doʊnt." bɑɹldən tʊk ə dʒɹɪŋk ə ti. "wi hæv ðə ɹulz. ɹulz ðət jə ɪɡnɔɹd. noʊ faɪɝz lɪɾ æftɝ sʌnsɛt - wi kæn əv ə bleɪz stɑɹɾɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪt, wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn tə faɪɾ ɪt. ən wi fɝbɪɾ aʊtsaɪɾɝz ɪnsaɪd ðə taʊn æftɝ sʌnsɛt. wi lɝn ðət lɛsən kwɪkli. ðə fɝs pipəl tʃɹæp hɪɹ æftɝ naɪtfɔl wɝ ɹɛləɾɪvz ə sæmɝi ðə kupɝ. wi faʊn blʌɾ ɑn ðə wɔlz ə hɪz hoʊm ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪz sɪstɝ ən əɹ fæmli wɝ seɪfli əslip ɪn ðə bɛdz hid ɡɪvən ðɛm." ðə meɪɝ pɔzd. "naʊ ðeɪv ðə seɪm naɪtmɛɹz wi du."

"We don't." Barlden took a drink of tea. "We have the rules. Rules that you ignored. No fires lit after sunset - we can't have a blaze starting in the night, without anyone to fight it. And we forbid outsiders inside the town after sunset. We learned that lesson quickly. The first people trapped here after nightfall were relatives of Sammrie the cooper. We found blood on the walls of his home the next morning. But his sister and her family were safely asleep in the beds he'd given them." The mayor paused. "Now they have the same nightmares we do."

"soʊ dʒʌs liv," mæt sɛd. "liv ðɪs blʌɾi pleɪs ən ɡoʊ sʌmwɛɹ ɛls!"

"So just leave," Mat said. "Leave this bloody place and go somewhere else!"

"wiv tʃɹaɪd," ðə meɪɝ sɛd. "wi ɔlweɪz weɪk ʌp bæk hɪɹ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fɑɹ wi ɡoʊ. səm əv tʃɹaɪɾ ɛndɪŋ ðɛɹ lɪvz. wi bɛɹid ðə bɑɾiz. ðeɪ woʊk ʌp ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ bɛdz."

"We've tried," the mayor said. "We always wake up back here, no matter how far we go. Some have tried ending their lives. We buried the bodies. They woke up the next morning in their beds."

ðə ɹum fɛl saɪlənt.

The room fell silent.

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz," mæt wɪspɝd. hi fɛl tʃɪld.

"Blood and bloody ashes," Mat whispered. He felt chilled.

"ju sɝvaɪv ðə naɪt," ðə meɪɝ sɛd, stɝɪŋ ɪz ti əɡɛn. "aɪ əsum ðət jə hædnt, æftɝ siɪŋ ðət blʌdsteɪn. wi wɝ kjʊɹiəs tə si wɛɹ jud weɪk ʌp. moʊst ə ðə ɹumz ɪn ði ɪnz ɑɹ pɝmənənli teɪkən baɪ tʃɹævəlɝz u ɑɹ naʊ, fəɹ bɛɾɝ əɹ wɝs, pɑɹɾ ʌv əɹ vɪlədʒ. wi ɑɹən eɪbəl tə tʃuz wɛɹ sʌmwʌn əweɪkənz. ɪt dʒʌs hæpənz. ən ɛmpti bɛd ɡɛts ə nu ɑkjəpənt, ən fɹəm ðən ɑn ðeɪ weɪk ʌp ðəɹ itʃ mɔɹnɪŋ.

"You survived the night," the mayor said, stirring his tea again. "I assumed that you hadn't, after seeing that bloodstain. We were curious to see where you'd wake up. Most of the rooms in the inns are permanently taken by travelers who are now, for better or worse, part of our village. We aren't able to choose where someone awakens. It just happens. An empty bed gets a new occupant, and from then on they wake up there each morning.

"ɛniweɪ, wən aɪ hɝd jə tɔkɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ əbaʊt wʌt jud sin, aɪ ɹilaɪz ðət jə mʌst əv ɪskeɪpt. jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə naɪt tu vɪvədli. ɛniwʌn u . . . dʒɔɪnz əs sɪmpli hæz ðə naɪtmɛɹz. kaʊn jʊɹsɛlvz lʌki. aɪ sədʒɛs jə muv ɑn ən fɝɡɛt hɪndɝstæp."

"Anyway, when I heard you talking to one another about what you'd seen, I realized that you must have escaped. You remember the night too vividly. Anyone who . . . joins us simply has the nightmares. Count yourselves lucky. I suggest you move on and forget Hinderstap."

"wi hæv ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ʌs," tɑm sɛd. "ðeɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə də sʌmθɪŋ tə hɛlp ju. wi kəd tɛl ðə waɪt taʊɝ, hæv əm sɛnd - "

"We have Aes Sedai with us," Thom said. "They might be able to do something to help you. We could tell the White Tower, have them send - "

"noʊ!" bɑɹldən sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "aʊɝ lɪvz ɑɹən soʊ bæd, naʊ ðət wi noʊ haʊ tə dil wɪð əɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən. wi doʊnt wɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ aɪz ɑn ʌs." hi tɝn əweɪ. "wi nɪɹli tɝn jəɹ ɡɹup əweɪ flæt. wi də ðæt, səmtaɪmz, ɪf wi sɛns ðət ðə tʃɹævəlɝz woʊn oʊbeɪ əɹ ɹulz. bʌt jə hæɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ju. ðeɪ æsk kwɛstʃənz, ðeɪ ɡɛt kjʊɹiəs. wi wɝid ðəɾ ɪf wi tɝn jə əweɪ, ðeɪd ɡɛt səspɪʃəs ən fɔɹs ɛntʃɹəns."

"No!" Barlden said sharply. "Our lives aren't so bad, now that we know how to deal with our situation. We don't want Aes Sedai eyes on us." He turned away. "We nearly turned your group away flat. We do that, sometimes, if we sense that the travelers won't obey our rules. But you had Aes Sedai with you. They ask questions, they get curious. We worried that if we turned you away, they'd get suspicious and force entrance."

"fɔɹsɪŋ əm tə liv ət sʌnsɛt meɪɾ əm ivən mɔɹ kjʊɹiəs," mæt sɛd. "æn hævɪŋ ðɛɹ beɪðɪŋ ətɛndəns blʌɾi tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl əm ɪzən ə ɡʊd weɪ tə kip ðə sikɹəɾ iðɝ."

"Forcing them to leave at sunset made them even more curious," Mat said. "And having their bathing attendants bloody try to kill them isn't a good way to keep the secret either."

ðə meɪɝ lʊkt wɑn. "sʌm wɪʃt . . . wɛl, ðət jud bi tʃɹæp hɪɹ. ðeɪ θɔt ðəɾ ɪf ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ baʊn hɪɹ, ðeɪd faɪn ə weɪ aʊt fəɹ ɔl ʌv ʌs. wi doʊn ɔl əɡɹi. iðɝ weɪ, ɪts əɹ pɹɑbləm. pliz, dʒʌst. . . . dʒʌst ɡoʊ."

The mayor looked wan. "Some wished . . . well, that you'd be trapped here. They thought that if Aes Sedai were bound here, they'd find a way out for all of us. We don't all agree. Either way, it's our problem. Please, just. . . . Just go."

"faɪn." mæt stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ən pɪkt ʌp ɪz spɪɹ. "bʌt fɝst, tɛl mi wɛɹ ðiz keɪm fɹʌm."

"Fine." Mat stood up straight and picked up his spear. "But first, tell me where these came from."

hi pʊl ðə peɪpɝ fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, ðə wʌn ðət bɔɹ ə dʒɹɔɪŋ ə hɪz feɪs.

He pulled the paper from his pocket, the one that bore a drawing of his face.

bɑɹldən ɡlænst əɾ ɪt. "jul faɪn ðoʊz spɹɛɾ ɝaʊn ðə nɪɹbaɪ vɪlədʒəz," hi sɛd. "sʌmwʌnz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju. əz aɪ toʊld lɛdʒɹən læs naɪt, aɪm nɑɾ ɪn ðə bɪznəs ə sɛlɪŋ aʊt ɡɛsts. aɪ wɑzn əbaʊt tə kɪdnæp jə ən ɹɪsk kipɪŋ jə hɪɹ oʊvɝnaɪt dʒʌs fəɹ səm ɹɪwɔɹd."

Barlden glanced at it. "You'll find those spread around the nearby villages," he said. "Someone's looking for you. As I told Ledron last night, I'm not in the business of selling out guests. I wasn't about to kidnap you and risk keeping you here overnight just for some reward."

"huz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi?" mæt ɹɪpiɾɪd.

"Who's looking for me?" Mat repeated.

"əbaʊt twɛnti liɡz tə ðə nɔɹθist, ðɛɹz ə smɔl taʊn kɔl tʃɹʌstɛɹ. ɹumɝ sɛz ðəɾ ɪf jə wɑn ə lɪɾəl kɔɪn, jə kən bɹɪŋ nuz əbaʊɾ ə mæn u lʊks laɪk ðə wʌn ɪn ðɪs pɪktʃɝ, əɹ ði ʌðɝ wʌn. vɪzəɾ ən ɪn ɪn tʃɹʌstɛɹ kɔl ðə ʃeɪkən fɪs tə faɪn ðə wʌn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju."

"About twenty leagues to the northeast, there's a small town called Trustair. Rumor says that if you want a little coin, you can bring news about a man who looks like the one in this picture, or the other one. Visit an inn in Trustair called The Shaken Fist to find the one looking for you."

"ʌðɝ pɪktʃɝ?" mæt æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"Other picture?" Mat asked, frowning.

"jɛs. ə bɝli fɛloʊ wɪð ə bɪɹd. ə noʊɾ ət ðə bɑɾəm sɛz hiz ɡoʊldən aɪz."

"Yes. A burly fellow with a beard. A note at the bottom says he has golden eyes."

mæt ɡlænst ət tɑm, hud ɹeɪzd ə bʊʃi aɪbɹaʊ.

Mat glanced at Thom, who'd raised a bushy eyebrow.

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz," mæt mʌɾɝd ən pʊl ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz hæt daʊn. hu wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɪm ən pɛɹɪn, ən wʌd ðeɪ wɑnt? "wil bi ɡoʊɪŋ, aɪ səpoʊz," hi sɛd. hi ɡlænst ət bɑɹldən. pʊɹ fɛloʊ. ðət wɛn fəɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ vɪlədʒ. bʌt wʌt wɑz mæt tə də əbaʊɾ ɪt? ðəɹ wɝ faɪts jə kəd wɪn, ən ʌðɝz jə dʒʌs hæd tə liv fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls.

"Blood and bloody ashes," Mat muttered and pulled the side of his hat down. Who was looking for him and Perrin, and what did they want? "We'll be going, I suppose," he said. He glanced at Barlden. Poor fellow. That went for the entire village. But what was Mat to do about it? There were fights you could win, and others you just had to leave for someone else.

"jɔɹ ɡoʊld ɪz ɑn ðə wæɡən aʊtsaɪd," ðə meɪɝ sɛd. "wi dɪdn teɪk ɛni fɹəm jəɹ wɪnɪŋz.

"Your gold is on the wagon outside," the mayor said. "We didn't take any from your winnings.

ðə fuɾ ɪz ðəɹ tu." hi mɛt mæts aɪz. "wi hoʊl tə əɹ wɝd, hɪɹ. ʌðɝ θɪŋz ɑɹ aʊɾ ʌv əɹ kəntʃɹoʊl, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli fəɹ ðoʊz u doʊn lɪsən tə ðə ɹulz. bʌt wi ɑɹən gɑnə ɹɑb ə mæn dʒʌs kəz hiz ən aʊtsaɪɾɝ."

The food is there too." He met Mat's eyes. "We hold to our word, here. Other things are out of our control, particularly for those who don't listen to the rules. But we aren't going to rob a man just because he's an outsider."

"maɪɾi tɑlɝən ə ju," mæt sɛd flætli, pʊlɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. "hæv ə ɡʊd deɪ, ðɛn, ən wən naɪt kʌmz, tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə kɪl ɛniwʌn aɪ wʊdn kɪl. tɑm, jə kʌmɪŋ?"

"Mighty tolerant of you," Mat said flatly, pulling open the door. "Have a good day, then, and when night comes, try not to kill anyone I wouldn't kill. Thom, you coming?"

ðə ɡlimən dʒɔɪn hɪm, lɪmpɪŋ slaɪtli fɹəm ɪz oʊld waʊnd. mæt ɡlæns bæk ət bɑɹldən, hu stʊd wɪð slivz ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹum, lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɾ ɪz tikʌp. hi sim laɪk i wɑz wɪʃɪŋ ðət kʌp hɛl sʌmθɪŋ ə lɪɾəl stʃɹɔŋɝ.

The gleeman joined him, limping slightly from his old wound. Mat glanced back at Barlden, who stood with sleeves rolled up in the center of the room, looking down at his teacup. He seemed like he was wishing that cup held something a little stronger.

"pʊɹ fɛloʊ," mæt sɛd, ðən stɛpt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ laɪɾ æftɝ tɑm ən pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɪm.

"Poor fellow," Mat said, then stepped out into the morning light after Thom and pulled the door shut behind him.

"aɪ əsum wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ æftɝ ðət pɝsən spɹɛɾɪŋ ɝaʊn pɪktʃɝz ə ju?" tɑm æskt.

"I assume we're going after that person spreading around pictures of you?" Thom asked.

"ɹaɪɾ əz laɪt, wi ɑɹ," mæt sɛd, taɪɪŋ ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ tə pɪps' sæɾəl. "ɪts ɑn ðə weɪ tə fɔɹ kɪŋz ɛniweɪ. əl lɛd jəɹ hɔɹs ɪf jə kən dʒɹaɪv ðə wæɡən."

"Right as Light, we are," Mat said, tying his ashandarei to Pips' saddle. "It's on the way to Four Kings anyway. I'll lead your horse if you can drive the wagon."

tɑm nɑɾəd. hi wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ðə meɪɝz hoʊm.

Thom nodded. He was studying the mayor's home.

"wʌt?" mæt æskt.

"What?" Mat asked.

"nʌθɪŋ, læd," ðə ɡlimən sɛd. "ɪts dʒʌst . . . wɛl, ɪts ə sæd teɪl. sʌmθɪŋz ɹɔŋ ɪn ðə wɝld. ðɛɹz ə snæɡ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn hɪɹ. ðə taʊn ənɹævəlz ət naɪt, ən ðən ðə wɝl tʃɹaɪz tə ɹisɛɾ ɪɾ itʃ mɔɹnɪŋ tə meɪk θɪŋz ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn."

"Nothing, lad," the gleeman said. "It's just . . . well, it's a sad tale. Something's wrong in the world. There's a snag in the Pattern here. The town unravels at night, and then the world tries to reset it each morning to make things right again."

"wɛl, ðeɪ ʃəd bi mɔɹ fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ," mæt sɛd. ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz hæd pʊl ðə fud-fɪld wæɡən ʌp waɪl mæt ən tɑm hæd bɪn tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð ðə meɪɝ. ɪt wɑz hɪtʃt tə tu stʃɹɔŋ dʒɹæf hɔɹsəz, tæn ə kʌlɝɪŋ ən waɪɾ ə huf.

"Well, they should be more forthcoming," Mat said. The villagers had pulled the food-filled wagon up while Mat and Thom had been chatting with the mayor. It was hitched to two strong draft horses, tan of coloring and wide of hoof.

"mɔɹ fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ?" tɑm æskt. "haʊ? ðə meɪɝ ɪz ɹaɪt, ðeɪ dɪd tʃɹaɪ tə wɔɹn ʌs."

"More forthcoming?" Thom asked. "How? The mayor is right, they did try to warn us."

mæt ɡɹʌntɪd, wɔkɪŋ oʊvɝ tə oʊpən ðə tʃɛst ən tʃɛk ɑn ɪz ɡoʊld. ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ, əz ðə meɪɝ hæd sɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ," hi sɛd. "ðeɪ kəd pʊɾ ʌp ə wɔɹnɪŋ saɪn əɹ sʌmθɪŋ. həloʊ. wɛlkəm tə hɪndɝstæp. wɪl mɝɾɝ jə ɪn ðə naɪɾ ən it jəɹ blʌɾi feɪs ɪf jə steɪ pæst sʌnsɛt. tʃɹaɪ ðə paɪz. mɑɹtnə beɪli meɪks əm fɹɛʃ deɪli."

Mat grunted, walking over to open the chest and check on his gold. It was there, as the mayor had said. "I don't know," he said. "They could put up a warning sign or something. Hello. Welcome to Hinderstap. We will murder you in the night and eat your bloody face if you stay past sunset. Try the pies. Martna Baily makes them fresh daily."

tɑm dɪdn tʃʌkəl. "pʊɹ teɪst, læd. ðɛɹz tu mʌtʃ tʃɹædʒəɾi ɪn ðɪs taʊn fəɹ lɛvɪɾi."

Thom didn't chuckle. "Poor taste, lad. There's too much tragedy in this town for levity."

"fʌni," mæt sɛd. hi kaʊntəɾ aʊɾ əbaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ ɡoʊld əz i fɪɡjɝd wəd bi ə ɡʊd pɹaɪs fəɹ ðə fuɾ ən ðə wæɡən. ðɛn, æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi æɾəd tɛn mɔɹ sɪlvɝ kɹaʊnz. hi sɛɾ ɔl ə ðɪs ɪn ə paɪl ɑn ðə meɪɝz dɔɹstɛp, ðən kloʊz ðə tʃɛst. "ðə mɔɹ tʃɹædʒɪk θɪŋz ɡɛt, ðə mɔɹ aɪ fil laɪk læfɪŋ."

"Funny," Mat said. He counted out about as much gold as he figured would be a good price for the food and the wagon. Then, after a moment, he added ten more silver crowns. He set all of this in a pile on the mayor's doorstep, then closed the chest. "The more tragic things get, the more I feel like laughing."

"ɑɹ wi ɹɪli gɑnə teɪk ðɪs wæɡən?"

"Are we really going to take this wagon?"

"wi nid ðə fud," mæt sɛd, læʃɪŋ ðə tʃɛs tə ðə bæk ə ðə wæɡən. sɛvɹəl lɑɹdʒ wilz ʌv waɪt tʃiz ən ə hæf dʌzən lɛɡz ə mʌɾən leɪ pɹɑmənənli əlɔŋsaɪd ðə kæsks ʌv eɪl. ðə fud smɛld ɡʊd, ən ɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld. "aɪ wʌn ɪt fɛɹ." hi ɡlænst ət ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz pæsɪŋ ɑn ðə stʃɹit. wən hid fɝst sin əm ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, hid θɔt ðə sloʊnəs ə ðɛɹ peɪs wɑz du tə ðə leɪzi neɪtʃɝ ə ðə maʊntən vɪlɪdʒɝz. naʊ ɪt stʃɹʌk ɪm ðət ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ ɹizən ɪntaɪɝli.

"We need the food," Mat said, lashing the chest to the back of the wagon. Several large wheels of white cheese and a half dozen legs of mutton lay prominently alongside the casks of ale. The food smelled good, and his stomach rumbled. "I won it fair." He glanced at the villagers passing on the street. When he'd first seen them the day before, he'd thought the slowness of their pace was due to the lazy nature of the mountain villagers. Now it struck him that there was another reason entirely.

hi tɝn bæk tə hɪz wɝk, tʃɛkɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz' hɑɹnəs. "æn aɪ doʊn fil ə bɪt bæd teɪkɪŋ ðə wæɡən ən hɔɹsəz. aɪ daʊt ðiz vɪlɪdʒɝz ɑɹ gɑnə bi duɪŋ mʌtʃ tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ. . . ."

He turned back to his work, checking the horses' harness. "And I don't feel a bit bad taking the wagon and horses. I doubt these villagers are going to be doing much traveling in the future. . . ."

tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn

CHAPTER 29

ɪndə bændɑɹ ɛbən mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd, hu daɪd kəz ə maɪ wiknəs.

Into Bandar Eban Moiraine Damodred, who died because of my weakness.

ɹænd sloʊd teɪdeɪʃɝ tə ə wɔk əz i pæs θɹu ðə mæsɪv ɡeɪtweɪ tə bændɑɹ ɛbən, hɪz ɑntʊɹɑʒ fɑloʊɪŋ, ɹæŋks ʌv il liɾɪŋ hɪm. ðə ɡeɪts wɝ sɛd tə bi kɑɹvd wɪð ðə sɪɾiz sil, bʌt swʌŋ oʊpən əz ðeɪ wɝ, ɹænd kʊdn si ðɛm.

Rand slowed Tai'daishar to a walk as he passed through the massive gateway to Bandar Eban, his entourage following, ranks of Aiel leading him. The gates were said to be carved with the city's seal, but swung open as they were, Rand couldn't see them.

ðə neɪmləs dɑɹkfɹɛn aɪ bɪhɛɾɪd ɪn ðoʊz mʊɹændiən hɪlz. aɪv fɝɡɑɾən ðə lʊks ə ði ʌðɝz wɪð hɝ, bʌɾ əl nɛvɝ fɝɡɛɾ əɹ feɪs.

The nameless Darkfriend I beheaded in those Murandian hills. I've forgotten the looks of the others with her, but I will never forget her face.

ðə lɪst ɹæn θɹu hɪz hɛd. ɔlmoʊst ə deɪli ɹɪtʃuəl naʊ, ðə neɪm ʌv ɛvɹi wʊmən u hæd daɪd baɪ hɪz hæn əɹ kəz ə hɪz ækʃənz. ðə stʃɹiɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɑz ə pækt ɝθ, laɪnd wɪð ɹʌts ðət kɹɪskɹɔst ət ði ɪntɝsɛkʃənz. ðə dɝt wɑz laɪɾɝ hɪɹ ðən i wɑz juz tə.

The list ran through his head. Almost a daily ritual now, the name of every woman who had died by his hand or because of his actions. The street inside the city was of packed earth, lined with ruts that crisscrossed at the intersections. The dirt was lighter here than he was used to.

koʊləveɪɪɹ seɪɡən, hu daɪd kəz aɪ meɪɾ əɹ ə pɔpɝ.

Colavaere Saighan, who died because I made her a pauper.

hi ɹoʊd pæst ɹæŋks ə dəmɑni, wɪmən ɪn daɪəfənəs ɡaʊnz, mɛn wɪð θɪn mʌstæʃɪz ən kʌlɝfəl koʊts. ðə ɹoʊdweɪz hɪɹ hæd wʊɾən bɔɹdwɔks ət ðə saɪdz, ən ðə pipəl kɹaʊɾəd ðɛm, wɑtʃɪŋ. ɹænd kəd hɪɹ bænɝz ən flæɡz flæpɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ðəɹ sim tə bi ə lɑɾ ə ðɛm ɪn ðə sɪɾi.

He rode past ranks of Domani, women in diaphanous gowns, men with thin mustaches and colorful coats. The roadways here had wooden boardwalks at the sides, and the people crowded them, watching. Rand could hear banners and flags flapping in the wind. There seemed to be a lot of them in the city.

ðə lɪst ɔlweɪz bɪɡæn wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. ðət neɪm hɝt ðə moʊst ʌv ɔl, fəɹ i cʊɾə seɪv hɝ.

The list always began with Moiraine. That name hurt the most of all, for he could have saved her.

hi ʃəd hæv. hi heɪɾəd hɪmsɛlf fəɹ əlaʊɪŋ əɹ tə sækɹəfaɪs hɝsɛlf fəɹ hɪm.

He should have. He hated himself for allowing her to sacrifice herself for him.

ə tʃaɪl stɛpt ɔf ðə bɔɹdwɔk ən stɑɹɾəd tə ɹʌn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, bʌɾ ɪz fɑðɝ kɑɾ ɪm baɪ ðə hæn ən hɔld ɪm bæk ɪndə ðə pɹɛs ə pipəl. səm kɔft ən mʌɾɝd, bʌt moʊst wɝ saɪlənt. ðə saʊnz ə ɹændz tʃɹups mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɑn ðə pækt ɝθ simd ə θʌndɝ baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən.

A child stepped off the boardwalk and started to run out into the street, but his father caught him by the hand and hauled him back into the press of people. Some coughed and muttered, but most were silent. The sounds of Rand's troops marching on the packed earth seemed a thunder by comparison.

wɑz lænfɝ əlaɪv əɡɛn? ɪf ɪʃəml kəd bi ɹɪtɝnd, wʌɾ əbaʊt hɝ? ɪn ðət keɪs, mɔɪɹeɪnz dɛθ hæd bɪn fəɹ nɔt, ən ɪz kaʊɝɾəs wɑz ivən mɔɹ ɡɔlɪŋ. nɛvɝ əɡɛn. ðə lɪst wəd ɹɪmeɪn, bʌɾ i wəd nɛvɝ əɡɛn bi tu wik tə də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn.

Was Lanfear alive again? If Ishamael could be returned, what about her? In that case, Moiraine's death had been for naught, and his cowardice was even more galling. Never again. The list would remain, but he would never again be too weak to do what must be done.

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɪɹz fɹəm ðə pipəl ɑn ðoʊz bɔɹdwɔks. wɛl, hi hæd nɑt kʌm tə lɪbɝeɪt. hi hæd kʌm tə də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn. pɝhæps i wəd faɪnd ɡɹeɪndəl hɪɹ; æzmɑɾiən sɛd ʃi hæd bɪn ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi, bʌt ðət hæd bɪn soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ɪf i faʊn hɝ, pɝhæps ðət wəɾ əsweɪdʒ ɪz kɑnʃəns əɾ ɪnveɪɾɪŋ.

There were no cheers from the people on those boardwalks. Well, he had not come to liberate. He had come to do what must be done. Perhaps he would find Graendal here; Asmodean said she had been in the country, but that had been so long ago. If he found her, perhaps that would assuage his conscience at invading.

dɪɾ i hæv wʌn ə ðoʊz ɛnimɔɹ? hi kəd nɑt dɪsaɪd.

Did he have one of those anymore? He could not decide.

laɪæ, ʌv ðə koʊseɪɾə tʃɑɝin, hum aɪ kɪld, tɛlɪŋ maɪsɛlf ɪt wɑz fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɡʊd. ɑdli, luz θɝɪn stɑɹɾəd tə tʃænt wɪð hɪm, ɹɛɾɪŋ ɔf ðə neɪmz, ə stʃɹeɪnʒ, ɛkoʊɪŋ tʃæn ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd.

Liah, of the Cosaida Chareen, whom I killed, telling myself it was for her own good. Oddly, Lews Therin started to chant with him, reading off the names, a strange, echoing chant inside his head.

əhɛd, ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup ʌv il stʊd weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm ɪn ə sɪɾi skwɛɹ sɛt wɪð kɑpɝ faʊntənz ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə hɔɹsəz lipɪŋ fɹəm ə fɹɔθi weɪv. ə mæn ɑn hɔɹsbæk weɪɾəd bɪfɔɹ ðə faʊntən, ən ɑnɝ ɡɑɹɾ ɝaʊn hɪm. hi wɑz ə sɑləd, skwɛɹ-feɪs mæn wɪð fɝoʊd skɪn ən ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ. hɪz fɔɹhɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd ən paʊɾɝd, æftɝ ðə fæʃən ə kɛɹhinɪn soʊlʒɝz. dɑbɹeɪn wɑz tʃɹʌstwɝði, əz mʌtʃ əz ɛni kɛɹhinɪn wɑz, ət list.

Ahead, a large group of Aiel stood waiting for him in a city square set with copper fountains in the shape of horses leaping from a frothy wave. A man on horseback waited before the fountain, an honor guard around him. He was a solid, square-faced man with furrowed skin and gray hair. His forehead was shaved and powdered, after the fashion of Cairhienin soldiers. Dobraine was trustworthy, as much as any Cairhienin was, at least.

sɛndɑɹə ʌv ði aɪɝn maʊntən tɑɹdæd, ləmɛl ə ðə smoʊk wɔɾɝ maɪæɡoʊmə, ænhaɪlɪn ə ðə ɹɛd sɔlt ɡoʊʃin.

Sendara of the Iron Mountain Taardad, Lamelle of the Smoke Water Miagoma, Andhilin of the Red Salt Goshien.

aɪlaɪɛnə θɝɪn mɔɝɛl, luz θɝɪn sɛd, slɪpɪŋ ðə neɪm ɪn bɪtwin tu ʌðɝz. ɹænd lɛɾ ɪt stænd. ət lis ðə mædmæn dɪdn skɹim əɡɛn.

Ilyena Therin Moerelle, Lews Therin said, slipping the name in between two others. Rand let it stand. At least the madman didn't scream again.

"lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," dɑbɹeɪn sɛd smuðli, boʊɪŋ tə ɹænd əz i əpɹoʊtʃt. "aɪ dɪlɪvɝ tə jə ðə sɪɾi ʌv bændɑɹ ɛbən. ɔɹɾɝ əz bɪn ɹɪstɔɹd, əz jə kəmændəd."

"Lord Dragon," Dobraine said smoothly, bowing to Rand as he approached. "I deliver to you the city of Bandar Eban. Order has been restored, as you commanded."

"aɪ æsk jə tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ tə ði ɪntaɪɝ kʌntʃɹi, dɑbɹeɪn," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "nɑt dʒʌst wʌn sɪɾi."

"I asked you to restore order to the entire country, Dobraine," Rand said softly. "Not just one city."

ðə noʊbəlmən wɪltɪd slaɪtli.

The nobleman wilted slightly.

"ju hæv wʌn ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl fəɹ mi?" ɹænd æskt.

"You have one of the merchant council for me?" Rand asked.

"jɛs," dɑbɹeɪn sɛd. "maɪləsɹ tʃædmɑɝ, læs tə fli ðə sɪɾiz keɪɑs." hɪz aɪz wɝ iɡɝ. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn stɔlwɝt, bʌt wɑz ðəɾ ə ɹuz? ɹænd hæd tʃɹʌbəl tʃɹʌstɪŋ ɛniwʌn leɪtli. ðə wʌnz u simd moʊs tʃɹʌstwɝði wɝ ðə wʌnz jə niɾəd tə wɑtʃ ðə moʊst. ən dɑbɹeɪn wɑz kɛɹhinɪn.

"Yes," Dobraine said. "Milisair Chadmar, last to flee the city's chaos." His eyes were eager. He had always been stalwart, but was that a ruse? Rand had trouble trusting anyone lately. The ones who seemed most trustworthy were the ones you needed to watch the most. And Dobraine was Cairhienin.

dɛɹd ɹænd tʃɹʌst ɛniwʌn fɹəm kɛɹhin, wɪð ðɛɹ ɡeɪmz?

Dared Rand trust anyone from Cairhien, with their games?

mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz kɛɹhinɪn. aɪ tʃɹʌstɪd hɝ. moʊsli.

Moiraine was Cairhienin. I trusted her. Mostly.

pɝhæps dɑbɹeɪn hoʊp ðət ɹænd wəd tʃuz ɪm əz kɪŋ ɪn ɑɹæd dumən. hi hæd bɪn stuɝɾ ə kɛɹhin, bʌɾ i - laɪk moʊst ʌðɝz - nu ðət ɹænd ɪntɛndəɾ ɪleɪn fəɹ ðə sʌn θɹoʊn.

Perhaps Dobraine hoped that Rand would choose him as king in Arad Doman. He had been steward of Cairhien, but he - like most others - knew that Rand intended Elayne for the Sun Throne.

wɛl, ɹænd maɪt ɡɪv ðɪs kɪŋdəm tə dɑbɹeɪn ət ðæt. hi wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən moʊst. ɹænd nɑɾəd fəɹ ɪm tə lid ðə weɪ, ən i dɪd soʊ, tɝnɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡɹup ʌv il tə mɑɹtʃ daʊn ə lɑɹdʒ saɪd stʃɹit. ɹænd kəntɪnjud, lɪst stɪl ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu hɪz maɪnd.

Well, Rand might give this kingdom to Dobraine at that. He was better than most. Rand nodded for him to lead the way, and he did so, turning with the group of Aiel to march down a large side street. Rand continued, list still running through his mind.

ðə bɪldɪŋz hɪɹ wɝ tɔl ən skwɛɹ, wɪð ðə ʃeɪp ə bɑksəz stækt ətɑp wʌn ənʌðɝ. mɛni ʌv əm hæd bælkəniz, pækt wɪð pipəl, laɪk ðə bɔɹdwɔks bɪniθ.

The buildings here were tall and square, with the shape of boxes stacked atop one another. Many of them had balconies, packed with people, like the boardwalks beneath.

itʃ neɪm ɑn ɹændz lɪs peɪn hɪm, bʌt ðət peɪn wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ, dɪstən θɪŋ naʊ. hɪz filɪŋz wɝ . . . dɪfɹən sɪns ðə deɪ hi hæd kɪl sɛmɝhɪdʒ. ʃi hæd tɔɾ ɪm haʊ tə bɛɹi hɪz ɡɪlt ən ɪz hɝt. ʃi hæd θɔt tə tʃeɪn hɪm, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd hæd ɡɪvən ɪm stʃɹɛŋkθ.

Each name on Rand's list pained him, but that pain was a strange, distant thing now. His feelings were . . . different since the day he had killed Semirhage. She had taught him how to bury his guilt and his hurt. She had thought to chain him, but instead had given him strength.

hi æɾəd əɹ neɪm ən ɛlzəz neɪm tə ðə lɪst. ðeɪ dɪdn əv ɛni ɹaɪt tə bi ðɛɹ. sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz lɛs ə wʊmən ən mɔɹ ə mɑnstɝ. ɛlzə hæd bɪtʃɹeɪd hɪm, sɝvɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ ɔl əlɔŋ. bʌɾ i æɾəd ðə neɪmz. ðeɪ hæɾ əz mʌtʃ kleɪm ɑn ɪm fəɹ kɪlɪŋ əm əz ɛni. mɔɹ, ivən. hi hæd bɪn ənwɪlɪŋ tə kɪl lænfɝ tə seɪv mɔɪɹeɪn, bʌɾ i hæd juz bɑlfaɪɝ tə bɝn sɛmɝhɪdʒ aʊɾ ʌv ɛɡzɪstəns ɹæðɝ ðən əlaʊ hɪmsɛlf tə bi kæptʃɝɾ əɡɛn.

He added her name and Elza's name to the list. They didn't have any right to be there. Semirhage was less a woman and more a monster. Elza had betrayed him, serving the Shadow all along. But he added the names. They had as much claim on him for killing them as any. More, even. He had been unwilling to kill Lanfear to save Moiraine, but he had used balefire to burn Semirhage out of existence rather than allow himself to be captured again.

hi fɪŋɡɝd ði ɑbʒɛkt i kæɹiɾ ɪn ə paʊtʃ ɑn ɪz sæɾəl. ɪt wɑz ə smuð fɪɡjɝin. hi hæd nɑt toʊl kædzueɪn ðəɾ ɪz sɝvəns hæd ɹəkʌvɝɾ ɪt fɹəm əɹ ɹum. naʊ ðət kædzueɪn wɑz ɛɡzaɪl fɹəm ɪz pɹɛzəns, hi nɛvɝ wʊd. hi nu ðət ʃi tæɡd əlɔŋ stɪl wɪð ɪz ɑntʊɹɑʒ, pʊʃɪŋ ðə lɪməts ə hɪz kəmæn tə nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɪm si hɝ feɪs. bʌt ʃi dɪɾ əz ɔɹɾɝd, ən soʊ hi lɛɾ ɪt bi. hi wəd nɑt spik tə hɝ, ən ʃi wəd nɑt spik tə hɪm.

He fingered the object he carried in a pouch on his saddle. It was a smooth figurine. He had not told Cadsuane that his servants had recovered it from her room. Now that Cadsuane was exiled from his presence, he never would. He knew that she tagged along still with his entourage, pushing the limits of his command to never let him see her face. But she did as ordered, and so he let it be. He would not speak to her, and she would not speak to him.

kædzueɪn hæd bɪn ə tul, ən ðət tul hæd pɹuvən ɪnɪfɛktɪv. hi dɪd nɑt ɹəɡɹɛt kæstɪŋ ɪɾ əsaɪd.

Cadsuane had been a tool, and that tool had proven ineffective. He did not regret casting it aside.

dʒɛnhaɪlɪn, meɪɾən ə ðə koʊl pik maɪæɡoʊmə, hi θɔt, luz θɝɪn mʌɾɝɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd hɪm.

Jendhilin, Maiden of the Cold Peak Miagoma, he thought, Lews Therin muttering alongside him.

ðə lɪst wɑz soʊ lɔŋ. ɪt wəd ɡɹoʊ bɪfɔɹ i daɪd.

The list was so long. It would grow before he died.

dɛθ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝid hɪm. faɪnəli, hi ʌndɝstʊd luz θɝɪnz kɹaɪz tə lɛɾ ɪɾ ɛnd. ɹænd dɪzɝv tə daɪ. wɑz ðəɹ ə dɛθ soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðəɾ ə mæn wəd nɛvɝ əv tə bi ɹibɔɹn? hi ɹitʃt ði ɛn ə ðə lɪst, faɪnəli. wʌns, hid ɹɪpiɾɪd ɪt tə kip hɪmsɛlf fɹəm fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ðə neɪmz. ðət wɑz nɑt pɑsəbəl naʊ; hi kəd nɑt fɝɡɛɾ əm ɪf i wɪʃt. hi ɹɪpiɾɪd əm əz ə ɹimaɪndɝ ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz.

Death no longer worried him. Finally, he understood Lews Therin's cries to let it end. Rand deserved to die. Was there a death so strong that a man would never have to be reborn? He reached the end of the list, finally. Once, he'd repeated it to keep himself from forgetting the names. That was not possible now; he could not forget them if he wished. He repeated them as a reminder of what he was.

bʌt luz θɝɪn hæd wʌn mɔɹ neɪm tə æd. ɛlmɪndʒɹeɪɾə fɑɹʃɔ, hi wɪspɝd.

But Lews Therin had one more name to add. Elmindreda Farshaw, he whispered.

ɹænd pʊl teɪdeɪʃɝ ʌp ʃɔɹt, stɑpɪŋ ɪz kɑləm ʌv il, sɑldəiən kævəlɹi, ən kæmp ətɛndəns ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə stʃɹit. dɑbɹeɪn tɝn bæk kwɛstʃənɪŋli ɑn ɪz waɪt stæljən.

Rand pulled Tai'daishar up short, stopping his column of Aiel, Saldaean cavalry, and camp attendants in the middle of the street. Dobraine turned back questioningly on his white stallion.

aɪ dɪd nɑt kɪl hɝ! ɹænd θɔt. luz θɝɪn, ʃi lɪvz ɑn. wi dɪdn kɪl hɝ! ðət wɑz sɛmɝhɪdʒ u wɑz tə bleɪm, ɪn ɛni keɪs.

I did not kill her! Rand thought. Lews Therin, she lives on. We didn't kill her! That was Semirhage who was to blame, in any case.

saɪləns. hi kəd stɪl fil ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɑn əɹ flɛʃ, skwizɪŋ, ɪmpəɾənt jɛɾ ɪnkɹɛɾəbli stʃɹɔŋ.

Silence. He could still feel his fingers on her flesh, squeezing, impotent yet incredibly strong.

ivən ɪf sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd bɪn bɪhaɪn ði ækʃənz, ɹænd wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd bɪn tu wik tə sɛn mɪn əweɪ ən pɹətɛk hɝ.

Even if Semirhage had been behind the actions, Rand was the one who had been too weak to send Min away and protect her.

hi hædn sɛn əɹ əweɪ. nɑt kəz i wɑz tu wik, bʌt kəz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ɪm hæd stɑp kɛɹɪŋ. nɑɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ - hi lʌvd əɹ fɪɹsli, ən ɔlweɪz wʊd. bʌɾ i nu ðət dɛθ, peɪn ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən keɪm ɪn ɪz weɪk, ən i dʒɹæɡd əm bɪhaɪn ɪm laɪk ə kloʊk. mɪn maɪt daɪ hɪɹ, bʌɾ ɪf i sɛn əɹ əweɪ, ʃi wəd bi ɪn dʒʌst əz mʌtʃ deɪnʒɝ. hɪz ɛnəmiz laɪkli səspɛktəd ðəɾ i lʌv hɝ.

He hadn't sent her away. Not because he was too weak, but because something in him had stopped caring. Not about her - he loved her fiercely, and always would. But he knew that death, pain and destruction came in his wake, and he dragged them behind him like a cloak. Min might die here, but if he sent her away, she would be in just as much danger. His enemies likely suspected that he loved her.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ seɪfti. ɪf ʃi daɪd, hi wəɾ æɾ əɹ tə ðə lɪst ən sʌfɝ fəɹ ɪt.

There was no safety. If she died, he would add her to the list and suffer for it.

hi stɑɹɾəd muvɪŋ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ kwɛstʃən kəd bi kɔl tə hɪz ækʃənz. teɪdeɪʃɝz hʊvz θʌmpt ɑn ði ɝθən stʃɹits, meɪd sɑf baɪ ðə hjumɪɾəti. ɹeɪnz keɪm ɔfən hɪɹ; bændɑɹ ɛbən wɑz ðə pɹaɪm pɔɹt sɪɾi ʌv ðə nɔɹθwɛst. ɪf ɪt wɑzn ə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi laɪk ðoʊz ɪn ðə saʊθ, ɪt wɑz stɪl ɪmpɹɛsɪv. ɹoʊ əpɑn ɹoʊ ʌv skwɛɹ haʊsəz, bɪlt ʌv wʊd, ɹɪdʒd ət ðə sɛkən ən θɝd stɔɹiz.

He started moving again before question could be called to his actions. Tai'daishar's hooves thumped on the earthen streets, made soft by the humidity. Rains came often here; Bandar Eban was the prime port city of the northwest. If it wasn't a great city like those in the south, it was still impressive. Row upon row of square houses, built of wood, ridged at the second and third stories.

ðeɪ lʊk laɪk tʃɪlʒɹənz blɑks, stækt ɑn tɑp ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ, soʊ pɝfəkli skwɛɹ wɪð ðə stɔɹiz dɪvaɪɾəd. ðeɪ fɪl ðə sɪɾi, ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn ə dʒɛntəl ɪnklaɪn tə ðə mæsɪv pɔɹt.

They looked like children's blocks, stacked on top of one another, so perfectly square with the stories divided. They filled the city, rolling down a gentle incline to the massive port.

ðə sɪɾi wɑz waɪɾəst ət ðə pɔɹt, meɪkɪŋ ɪt sim laɪk ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə mæn oʊpənɪŋ ɪz maʊθ waɪd, əz ɪf tə dʒɹɪŋk ɪn ði oʊʃən ɪtsɛlf. ðə dɑks wɝ nɪɹli ɛmpti; ði oʊnli ʃɪps mʊɹd wɝ ə klʌstɝ ə si foʊk vɛsəlz - θɹi-mæstəd ɹeɪkɝz - ən səm fɪʃɪŋ tʃɹɔlɝz. ðə mæsɪv saɪz ə ðə pɔɹɾ oʊnli meɪɾ ɪt lʊk mɔɹ dɛsələt fəɹ ðə læk ə ʃɪps.

The city was widest at the port, making it seem like the head of a man opening his mouth wide, as if to drink in the ocean itself. The docks were nearly empty; the only ships moored were a cluster of Sea Folk vessels - three-masted rakers - and some fishing trawlers. The massive size of the port only made it look more desolate for the lack of ships.

ðət wɑz ðə fɝst saɪn ðəɾ ɔl wɑz nɑt wɛl ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən.

That was the first sign that all was not well in Bandar Eban.

ʌðɝ ðən ðə vɝtʃuəli ənɑkjəpaɪd hɑɹbɝ, ðə moʊs dɪstɪŋktɪv æspɛkt ə ðə sɪɾi wɑz ðə bænɝz.

Other than the virtually unoccupied harbor, the most distinctive aspect of the city was the banners.

ðeɪ flu əbʌv - əɹ hʌŋ fɹəm - ɛvɹi bɪldɪŋ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hʌmbəl. mɛni ʌv ðoʊz bænɝz pɹoʊkleɪm ðə tʃɹeɪd pɹæktəst ɪn ə ɡɪvən bɪldɪŋ - mʌtʃ əz ə sɪmpəl wʊɾən saɪn wəɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðə bænɝz wɝ fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪkstʃɹævəɡən ðən moʊst, bɹaɪt-kʌlɝɾ ən flʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn əbʌv ðə bɪldɪŋz. mætʃɪŋ tæpəstʃɹi-laɪk bænɝz hʌŋ fɹəm ðə saɪdz ə moʊs bɪldɪŋz, ənaʊnsɪŋ ɪn bɹaɪt lɛɾɝɪŋ ði oʊnɝ, mæstɝ kɹæfsmən ən mɝtʃən ʌv itʃ ʃɑp. ivən hoʊmz bɔɹ bænɝz wɪð ðə neɪmz ə ðə fæmliz u lɪv ðɛɹɪn.

They flew above - or hung from - every building, no matter how humble. Many of those banners proclaimed the trade practiced in a given building - much as a simple wooden sign would in Caemlyn. The banners were far more extravagant than most, bright-colored and fluttering in the wind above the buildings. Matching tapestry-like banners hung from the sides of most buildings, announcing in bright lettering the owner, master craftsman and merchant of each shop. Even homes bore banners with the names of the families who lived therein.

kɑpɝ-skɪn ən dɑɹk-hɛɹd, ðə dəmɑni feɪvɝd bɹaɪt kloʊðɪŋ. dəmɑni wɪmən wɝ ɪnfəməs fəɹ ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz, wɪtʃ wɝ fɪlmi ɪnʌf tə bi skændələs. ɪt wɑz sɛd ðət vɛɹi jʌŋ dəmɑni ɡɝlz pɹæktəs ði ɑɹɾ ə mənɪpjəleɪɾɪŋ mɛn, pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə deɪ wən ðeɪ wəd bi ʌv eɪdʒ.

Copper-skinned and dark-haired, the Domani favored bright clothing. Domani women were infamous for their dresses, which were filmy enough to be scandalous. It was said that very young Domani girls practiced the art of manipulating men, preparing for the day when they would be of age.

ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm ɔl stændɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊdz, wɑtʃɪŋ, wɑz nɪɹli spɛktəkəl ɪnʌf tə dʒɹɔ ɹænd aʊɾ ə hɪz bɹuɾɪŋ. pɝhæps ə jɪɹ əɡoʊ, hi wəɾ əv ɡɔkt, bʌt naʊ hi bɛɹli ɡeɪv əm ə ɡlæns. ɪn fækt, ɪt keɪm tə hɪm ðət dəmɑni pipəl wɝ fɑɹ lɛs stʃɹaɪkɪŋ wən ɡæðɝd təɡɛðɝ laɪk ðɪs. ə flaʊɝ ɪn ə fild ʌv widz wɑz ɔlweɪz ə saɪt, bʌɾ ɪf jə pæs kʌltəveɪɾəd flaʊɝ bɛdz ɛvɹi deɪ, nʌn ə ðɛm dʒɹu jəɹ noʊɾəs.

The sight of them all standing along the roads, watching, was nearly spectacle enough to draw Rand out of his brooding. Perhaps a year ago, he would have gawked, but now he barely gave them a glance. In fact, it came to him that Domani people were far less striking when gathered together like this. A flower in a field of weeds was always a sight, but if you passed cultivated flower beds every day, none of them drew your notice.

dɪstʃɹæktəd ðoʊ hi wɑz, hi dɪd pɪk aʊt ðə saɪnz ə stɑɹveɪʃən. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðət hɔntəd kæs tə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, ðət lin lʊk tə ðə feɪsəz ə ði ədʌls. ðɪs sɪɾi hæd bɪn ɪn keɪɑs dʒʌst wiks əɡoʊ, ðoʊ dɑbɹeɪn ən ði il hæd ɹɪstɔɹd ðə lɔ. səm ə ðə bɪldɪŋz bɔɹ pʊɹli mɛndɪd wɪndoʊz əɹ bɹoʊkən bɔɹdz, ən səm ə ðə bænɝz hæɾ ɑbviəsli bɪn ɹɪpt ɹisənli ən ʃɑɾəli mɛndɪd. lɔ hæd bɪn ɹɪstɔɹd, bʌt ðə læk ʌv ɪt wɑz stɪl ə fɹɛʃ mɛmɹi.

Distracted though he was, he did pick out the signs of starvation. There was no mistaking that haunted cast to the children, that lean look to the faces of the adults. This city had been in chaos just weeks ago, though Dobraine and the Aiel had restored the law. Some of the buildings bore poorly mended windows or broken boards, and some of the banners had obviously been ripped recently and shoddily mended. Law had been restored, but the lack of it was still a fresh memory.

ɹændz ɡɹup ɹitʃt ə sɛntʃɹəl kɹɔsɹoʊdz, pɹoʊkleɪm baɪ lɑɹdʒ flæpɪŋ bænɝz tə bi ɝɑndi skwɛɹ, ən dɑbɹeɪn tɝn ðə pɹəsɛʃən tə ði ist. mɛni ʌv ði il wɪð ðə kɛɹhinɪn wɔɹ ðə ɹɛd hɛdbæn mɑɹkɪŋ əm əz sɪswaɪəmən. spɪɹz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. ɹəɑɹk hæd səm twɛnti θaʊzən il kæmpt ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi ən ɪn ðə nɪɹbaɪ taʊnz; baɪ naʊ moʊs dəmɑni wəd noʊ ðət ðiz il fɑloʊd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Rand's group reached a central crossroads, proclaimed by large flapping banners to be Arandi Square, and Dobraine turned the procession to the east. Many of the Aiel with the Cairhienin wore the red headband marking them as siswai'aman. Spears of the Dragon. Rhuarc had some twenty thousand Aiel camped around the city and in the nearby towns; by now most Domani would know that these Aiel followed the Dragon Reborn.

ɹænd wɑz ɡlæd tə faɪn ðət ðə si foʊk ɹeɪkɝz hæɾ ɝaɪvd - faɪnəli - wɪð ɡɹeɪn fɹəm ðə saʊθ.

Rand was glad to find that the Sea Folk rakers had arrived - finally - with grain from the south.

hoʊpfəli, ðət wəd də əz mʌtʃ tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ əz dɑbɹeɪn ən ði il hæd.

Hopefully, that would do as much to restore order as Dobraine and the Aiel had.

ðə pɹəsɛʃən tɝn ɪndə ðə wɛlθi sɛkʃən ə ðə sɪɾi. hi nu wɛɹ ðeɪd faɪn ɪt lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə hoʊmz stɑɹɾəd lʊkɪŋ mɔɹ lævɪʃ: əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə dɑks əz pɑsəbəl, waɪl stɪl ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ə kʌmftəɹbəl dɪstəns fɹəm ðə sɪɾi wɔlz. ɹænd cʊɾə faʊn ðə ɹɪtʃ ivən wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə mæp. ðə sɪɾiz lændskeɪp ɔl bʌt dɪmændəd ðɛɹ loʊkeɪʃən.

The procession turned into the wealthy section of the city. He knew where they'd find it long before the homes started looking more lavish: as far from the docks as possible, while still remaining a comfortable distance from the city walls. Rand could have found the rich even without looking at a map. The city's landscape all but demanded their location.

ə hɔɹs klɑpt ʌp bɪsaɪd ɹænd. ət fɝst, hi əsumd ɪt wəd bi mɪn - bʌt noʊ, ʃi wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz. dɪd ʃi lʊk əɾ ɪm dɪfɹənli naʊ, əɹ wɑz i dʒʌst ɪmædʒənɪŋ ɪt? dɪd ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz əɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi sɔ hɪz feɪs?

A horse clopped up beside Rand. At first, he assumed it would be Min - but no, she was riding behind, with the Wise Ones. Did she look at him differently now, or was he just imagining it? Did she remember his fingers at her throat every time she saw his face?

ɪt wɑz mɛɹaɪs u hæd muvd ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə plæsəd dʌn mɛɹ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾəd baɪ ɹændz ɛɡzaɪl ə kædzueɪn. ənsɝpɹaɪzɪŋ. ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪk tə meɪnteɪn ə vɛɹi kɑm ən kəntʃɹoʊl fɹʌnt, bʌt mɛɹaɪs ən ði ʌðɝz hæd pændɝd tə kædzueɪn mʌtʃ laɪk ə vɪlədʒ ɪnkipɝ sɪmpɝɪŋ oʊvɝ ə vɪzəɾɪŋ kɪŋ.

It was Merise who had moved up beside him, riding a placid dun mare. The Aes Sedai was infuriated by Rand's exile of Cadsuane. Unsurprising. Aes Sedai liked to maintain a very calm and controlled front, but Merise and the others had pandered to Cadsuane much like a village innkeeper simpering over a visiting king.

ðə tæɹɑbənɝ wʊmən hæd tʃoʊzən tə wɛɹ əɹ ʃɔl tədeɪ, pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ əɹ əfɪlieɪʃən tə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. ʃi wɔɹ ɪt, pɝhæps, ɪn ən ɛfɝt tə ɹiɪnfɔɹs əɹ əθɔɹəɾi. ɪnwɝdli, ɹænd saɪd. hi hæd bɪn ɪkspɛktɪŋ ə kɑnfɹənteɪʃən, bʌɾ i hæd hoʊp ðət ðə bɪznəs ə ðə muv wəd dɪleɪ ɪɾ əntɪl tɛmpɝz səbsaɪɾɪd. hi ɹɪspɛktɪd kædzueɪn, æftɝ ə fæʃən, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ tʃɹʌstɪd hɝ. ðəɹ hæd tə bi kɑnsəkwɛnsəz fəɹ feɪljɝ, ən i fɛlt ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɪlif fɹəm hævɪŋ dɛlt wɪð hɝ. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ mɔɹ ə hɝ stʃɹɪŋz ɹæpɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɝaʊn hɪm.

The Taraboner woman had chosen to wear her shawl today, proclaiming her affiliation to the Green Ajah. She wore it, perhaps, in an effort to reinforce her authority. Inwardly, Rand sighed. He had been expecting a confrontation, but he had hoped that the business of the move would delay it until tempers subsided. He respected Cadsuane, after a fashion, but he had never trusted her. There had to be consequences for failure, and he felt a great relief from having dealt with her. There would be no more of her strings wrapping themselves around him.

ɔɹ, ət list, fjuɝ ə ðɛm.

Or, at least, fewer of them.

"ðɪs ɛɡzaɪl, ɪts fulɪʃ, ɹænd ælθɹ," mɛɹaɪs sɛd dɪsmɪsɪvli. wɑz ʃi ɪntɛnʃənəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹaɪl hɪm, pɝhæps tə meɪk ɪm iziɝ tə bʊli? æftɝ mʌnθs ə dilɪŋ wɪð kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf, ðɪs wʊmənz peɪl ɪməteɪʃən wɑz ɔlmoʊst əmjuzɪŋ.

"This exile, it is foolish, Rand al'Thor," Merise said dismissively. Was she intentionally trying to rile him, perhaps to make him easier to bully? After months of dealing with Cadsuane herself, this woman's pale imitation was almost amusing.

"ju ʃəd bɛɡ fəɹ əɹ fɝɡɪvnəs," mɛɹaɪs kəntɪnjud. "ʃi hæz kɑndəsɛndəd tə kəntɪnju wɪð ʌs, ðoʊ jəɹ ɪneɪn ɹistʃɹɪkʃən əz fɔɹst əɹ tə wɛɹ ə kloʊk wɪð ðə hʊɾ ʌp, dɪspaɪt ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə deɪ. jə ʃəd bi əʃeɪmd."

"You should beg for her forgiveness," Merise continued. "She has condescended to continue with us, though your inane restriction has forced her to wear a cloak with the hood up, despite the warmth of the day. You should be ashamed."

kædzueɪn əɡɛn. hi ʃʊdn əv lɛft əɹ ɹum tə wɪɡəl ɝaʊn ɪz kəmænd.

Cadsuane again. He shouldn't have left her room to wiggle around his command.

"wɛl?" mɛɹaɪs æskt.

"Well?" Merise asked.

ɹænd tɝn ɪz hɛɾ ən lʊk mɛɹaɪs ɪn ði aɪz. hi hæd dɪskʌvɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʃɑkɪŋ dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs fju aʊɝz. baɪ bɑɾəlɪŋ ʌp ðə siθɪŋ fjʊɹi wɪðɪn ɪm - baɪ bɪkʌmɪŋ kwəndɪlɝ - hi hæd ɡeɪn ən ʌndɝstændɪŋ ðət hæd lɔŋ ɪluɾɪd hɪm.

Rand turned his head and looked Merise in the eyes. He had discovered something shocking during the last few hours. By bottling up the seething fury within him - by becoming cuendillar - he had gained an understanding that had long eluded him.

pipəl dɪd nɑt ɹɪspɑn tə æŋɡɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɹɪspɑn tə dɪmænz. saɪləns ən kwɛstʃənz, ðiz wɝ fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪfɛktɪv. ɪndid, mɛɹaɪs - ə fʊli tʃɹeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ - wɪltɪd bɪfɔɹ ðət stɛɹ.

People did not respond to anger. They did not respond to demands. Silence and questions, these were far more effective. Indeed, Merise - a fully trained Aes Sedai - wilted before that stare.

hi pʊt noʊ ɪmoʊʃən ɪndə ɪt. hɪz ɹeɪdʒ, hɪz æŋɡɝ, hɪz pæʃən - ɪt wɑz ɔl stɪl ðɛɹ, bɛɹid wɪðɪn.

He put no emotion into it. His rage, his anger, his passion - it was all still there, buried within.

bʌɾ i hæd sɝaʊndəɾ ɪt wɪð aɪs, koʊld ən ɪmoʊbəlaɪzɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ði aɪs ə ðə pleɪs sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd tɔɾ ɪm tə ɡoʊ, ðə pleɪs ðət wɑz laɪk ðə vɔɪd, bʌt fɑɹ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs.

But he had surrounded it with ice, cold and immobilizing. It was the ice of the place Semirhage had taught him to go, the place that was like the void, but far more dangerous.

pɝhæps mɛɹaɪs kəd sɛns fɹoʊzən ɹeɪdʒ wɪðɪn hɪm. əɹ pɝhæps ʃi kəd sɛns ði ʌðɝ θɪŋ, ðə fæk ðət hid juz ðət . . . paʊɝ. dɪstənli, luz θɝɪn bɪɡæn tə kɹaɪ. ðə mædmæn dɪd ðət wɛnɛvɝ ɹænd θɔɾ ʌv wʌɾ i hæd dʌn tə ɪskeɪp sɛmɝhɪdʒəz kɑlɝ.

Perhaps Merise could sense frozen rage within him. Or perhaps she could sense the other thing, the fact that he'd used that . . . power. Distantly, Lews Therin began to cry. The madman did that whenever Rand thought of what he had done to escape Semirhage's collar.

"wʌt jə dɪd, ɪt wɑz ə fulɪʃ muv," mɛɹaɪs kəntɪnjud. "ju ʃəd - "

"What you did, it was a foolish move," Merise continued. "You should - "

"du jə θɪŋk mi ə ful, ðɛn?" ɹænd æsk sɔfli.

"Do you think me a fool, then?" Rand asked softly.

ɹɪspɑn tə dɪmænz wɪð saɪləns, ɹɪspɑn tə tʃælənʒɪz wɪð kwɛstʃənz. ɪt wɑz əmeɪzɪŋ haʊ ɪt wɝkt. mɛɹaɪs kʌɾ ɔf, ðən ʃɪvɝd vɪzəbli. ʃi ɡlæns daʊn, tə ðə paʊtʃ ɑn ɪz sæɾəl wɛɹ i kæɹid ðə smɔl stætʃu ʌv ə mæn hoʊldɪŋ əlɔft ə sfɪɹ. ɹænd fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪt, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz lusli.

Respond to demands with silence, respond to challenges with questions. It was amazing how it worked. Merise cut off, then shivered visibly. She glanced down, to the pouch on his saddle where he carried the small statue of a man holding aloft a sphere. Rand fingered it, holding his reins loosely.

hi dɪd nɑt flɔn ðə stætʃuɛt. hi sɪmpli kæɹiɾ ɪt, bʌt mɛɹaɪs ən moʊst ə ði ʌðɝz nu ðə nɪɹli ənlɪməɾəd paʊɝ i kəd tæp ɪf i wɪʃt. ɪt wɑz ə wɛpən ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ ɛvɝ noʊn.

He did not flaunt the statuette. He simply carried it, but Merise and most of the others knew the nearly unlimited power he could tap if he wished. It was a weapon greater than any other ever known.

wɪð ɪt, hi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ənaɪəleɪt ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf. ən ɪt sæɾ ɪnəsənli ɑn ɪz sæɾəl. ðət hæɾ ən ɪfɛkt ɑn pipəl.

With it, he might be able to annihilate the world itself. And it sat innocently on his saddle. That had an effect on people.

"aɪ . . . noʊ, aɪ doʊnt," ʃi ədmɪɾəd. "nɑɾ ɔlweɪz."

"I . . . No, I don't," she admitted. "Not always."

"du jə θɪŋk ðət feɪljɝz ʃəd bi ənpʌnɪʃt?" ɹænd æskt, vɔɪs stɪl sɑft. waɪ hæɾ i lɔst ɪz tɛmpɝ? ðiz lɪɾəl ənɔɪənsɪz wɝ nɑt wɝθ ɪz pæʃən, hɪz fjʊɹi. ɪf wʌn bɑðɝɾ ɪm tu mʌtʃ, ɔl i niɾəd də wɑz snʌf ɪɾ aʊt, laɪk ə kændəl.

"Do you think that failures should be unpunished?" Rand asked, voice still soft. Why had he lost his temper? These little annoyances were not worth his passion, his fury. If one bothered him too much, all he needed do was snuff it out, like a candle.

ə deɪnʒɝəs θɔt. hæd ðət bɪn hɪz? hæɾ ɪt bɪn luz θɝɪnz? əɹ . . . hæd ðə θɔt kʌm fɹəm . . . ɛlswɛɹ?

A dangerous thought. Had that been his? Had it been Lews Therin's? Or . . . had the thought come from . . . elsewhere?

"ʃʊɹli juv bɪn tu hɑɹʃ," mɛɹaɪs sɛd.

"Surely you have been too harsh," Merise said.

"tu hɑɹʃ?" hi æskt. "du jə ɹilaɪz əɹ mɪsteɪk, mɛɹaɪs? hæv jə kənsɪɾɝd wʌt kəɾ əv hæpənd? wʌt ʃəɾ əv hæpənd?"
