"Too harsh?" he asked. "Do you realize her mistake, Merise? Have you considered what could have happened? What should have happened?"

"aɪ - "

"I - "

"ði ɛn ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, mɛɹaɪs," hi wɪspɝd. "ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪð kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

"The end of all things, Merise," he whispered. "The Dark One with control of the Dragon Reborn.

ðə tu ʌv ʌs, faɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə seɪm saɪd."

The two of us, fighting on the same side."

ʃi fɛl saɪlənt, ðən sɛd, "jɛs. bʌt mɪsteɪks, jə jɝsɛlf əv meɪd ðɛm. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv ɛndəɾ ɪn sɪməlɝ dɪzæstɝ."

She fell silent, then said, "Yes. But mistakes, you yourself have made them. They might have ended in similar disaster."

"aɪ peɪ fəɹ maɪ mɪsteɪks," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. "aɪ peɪ fəɹ əm itʃ deɪ. itʃ aʊɝ. itʃ bɹɛθ."

"I pay for my mistakes," he said, turning away. "I pay for them each day. Each hour. Each breath."

"aɪ - "

"I - "

"ɪnʌf." hi dɪd nɑt jɛl ðə wɝd. hi spoʊk fɝmli, bʌt kwaɪətli. hi meɪɾ əɹ fil ðə fʊl fɔɹs ə hɪz dɪsplɛʒɝ, hɪz ɡeɪz sizɪŋ əɹ oʊn. ʃi sʌɾənli slʌmpt ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, lʊkɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm wɪð waɪɾ aɪz.

"Enough." He did not yell the word. He spoke firmly, but quietly. He made her feel the full force of his displeasure, his gaze seizing her own. She suddenly slumped in her saddle, looking up at him with wide eyes.

ðəɹ wɑz ə laʊd kɹækɪŋ nɔɪz fɹəm ðə saɪd, fɑloʊd baɪ ə sʌɾən kɹæʃ. skɹimz bɹoʊk ði ɛɹ. ɹænd tɝnd wɪð əlɑɹm. ə bælkəni fɪld wɪð ɔnlʊkɝz hæd bɹoʊkən fɹi ʌv ɪts səpɔɹts ən fɔlən tə ðə stʃɹit, smæʃɪŋ laɪk ə bæɹəl hɪt baɪ ə boʊldɝ. pipəl ɡɹoʊn ɪn peɪn, ʌðɝz kɔld aʊt fəɹ hɛlp. bʌt ðə saʊnz hæd kʌm fɹəm boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə stʃɹit. ɹænd fɹaʊn ən tɝnd; ə sɛkən bælkəni - dɝɛkli əkɹɔs fɹəm ðə fɝst - hæd fɔlən əz wɛl.

There was a loud cracking noise from the side, followed by a sudden crash. Screams broke the air. Rand turned with alarm. A balcony filled with onlookers had broken free of its supports and fallen to the street, smashing like a barrel hit by a boulder. People groaned in pain, others called out for help. But the sounds had come from both sides of the street. Rand frowned and turned; a second balcony - directly across from the first - had fallen as well.

mɛɹaɪs peɪld, ðən tɝn əɹ hɔɹs heɪstəli, hɛɾɪŋ tə hɛlp ðə wundəd. ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi hɝiɪŋ tə hil ðoʊz u hæd fɔlən.

Merise paled, then turned her horse hastily, heading to help the wounded. Other Aes Sedai were already hurrying to Heal those who had fallen.

ɹænd nid teɪdeɪʃɝ fɔɹwɝd. ðət hæd nɑt bɪn kɑz baɪ ðə paʊɝ, bʌt baɪ hɪz tɑvɝən neɪtʃɝ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ pɹɑbəbɪləɾi. wɛɹɛvɝ i vɪzəɾəd, ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl ən ɹændəm ɪvɛns əkɝd. lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə bɝθs, dɛθs, wɛɾɪŋz ən æksəɾənts. hi hæd lɝn tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛm.

Rand kneed Tai'daishar forward. That had not been caused by the Power, but by his ta'veren nature changing probability. Wherever he visited, remarkable and random events occurred. Large numbers of births, deaths, weddings and accidents. He had learned to ignore them.

hi hæd ɹɛɹli sin ən əkɝəns kwaɪt soʊ . . . vaɪələnt, haʊɛvɝ. kəɾ i bi ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑzn du tə səm ɪntɝækʃən wɪð ðə nu fɔɹs? ðəɾ ənsin jɛt tɛmptɪŋ wɛl ə paʊɝ ɹænd hæd tæpt, juzd ən ɛndʒɔɪd? luz θɝɪn θɔt wʌt hæpənd ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪmpɑsəbəl.

He had rarely seen an occurrence quite so . . . violent, however. Could he be sure it wasn't due to some interaction with the new force? That unseen yet tempting well of power Rand had tapped, used and enjoyed? Lews Therin thought what happened should have been impossible.

ði ɝɪdʒənəl ɹizən mænkaɪn hæd bɔɹɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən hæd bɪn paʊɝ. ə nu sɔɹs ʌv ɛnɝdʒi fəɹ tʃænəlɪŋ, laɪk ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌt dɪfɹənt. ənnoʊn ən stʃɹeɪnʒ, ən pətɛnʃəli væst. ðət sɔɹs ə paʊɝ hæd tɝn aʊt tə bi ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf.

The original reason mankind had bored into the Dark One's prison had been power. A new source of energy for channeling, like the One Power, but different. Unknown and strange, and potentially vast. That source of power had turned out to be the Dark One himself.

luz θɝɪn wɪmpɝd.

Lews Therin whimpered.

ɹænd kæɹid ði æksɛs ki wɪð ɪm fəɹ ə ɹizən. ɪt lɪŋkt ɪm tə wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst sɑŋɡɹil ɛvɝ kɹieɪɾəd. wɪð ðət paʊɝ ən ði eɪɾ ə nɪneɪiv, ɹænd hæd klɛnz seɪɾɪn. ði æksɛs ki hæɾ əlaʊɾ ɪm tə tæp ən ʌnɪmædʒɪnəbəl ɹɪvɝ, ə tɛmpəst əz væst əz ði oʊʃən. ɪt hæd bɪn ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst θɪŋ i hæɾ ɛvɝ ɪkspɪɹiənst.

Rand carried the access key with him for a reason. It linked him to one of the greatest sa'angreal ever created. With that power and the aid of Nynaeve, Rand had cleansed saidin. The access key had allowed him to tap an unimaginable river, a tempest as vast as the ocean. It had been the greatest thing he had ever experienced.

əntɪl ðə moʊmənt wən i hæd juz ði ənneɪm paʊɝ.

Until the moment when he had used the unnamed power.

ðəɾ ʌðɝ fɔɹs kɔl tə hɪm, sæŋ tə hɪm, tɛmptəd hɪm. soʊ mʌtʃ paʊɝ, soʊ mʌtʃ dɪvaɪn wʌndɝ.

That other force called to him, sang to him, tempted him. So much power, so much divine wonder.

bʌɾ ɪt tɛɹəfaɪd hɪm. hi dɪdn dɛɹ tʌtʃ ɪt, nɑɾ əɡɛn.

But it terrified him. He didn't dare touch it, not again.

ən soʊ hi kæɹid ðə ki. hi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən wɪtʃ ə ðə tu sɔɹsəz ʌv ɛnɝdʒi wɑz mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs, bʌɾ əz lɔŋ əz boʊθ kɔl tə hɪm, hi wɑz eɪbəl tə ɹɪzɪs boʊθ. laɪk tu pipəl, boʊθ jɛlɪŋ fəɹ ɪz ətɛnʃən, ðeɪ dʒɹaʊnd wʌn ənʌðɝ aʊt. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt.

And so he carried the key. He was not certain which of the two sources of energy was more dangerous, but as long as both called to him, he was able to resist both. Like two people, both yelling for his attention, they drowned one another out. For the moment.

bɪsaɪdz, hi wəd nɑt bi kɑlɝɾ əɡɛn. ði æksɛs ki wʊdn əv hɛlpt ɪm əɡɛnst sɛmɝhɪdʒ - noʊ əmaʊn ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ wəɾ eɪɾ ə mæn ɪf i wɝ kɑɾ ʌnəwɛɹ - bʌt pɝhæps ɪt wəɾ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ. wʌns, hi hædn dɛɹd kæɹi ɪt fəɹ fɪɹ ʌv wʌɾ ɪɾ ɔfɝd. hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hæd ɹum tə ɪndʌlʒ sətʃ wiknəs.

Besides, he would not be collared again. The access key wouldn't have helped him against Semirhage - no amount of the One Power would aid a man if he were caught unaware - but perhaps it would in the future. Once, he hadn't dared carry it for fear of what it offered. He no longer had room to indulge such weakness.

ðə dɛstəneɪʃən wɑz izi tə pɪk aʊt; əbaʊt faɪv hʌnʒɹəd kɛɹhinɪn ɑɹmmɪn wɝ kæmpt ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnz ʌv ə speɪʃəs, steɪtli mænʃən. il ɔlsoʊ hæd tɛns ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnz - bʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlsoʊ kleɪm nɪɹbaɪ bɪldɪŋz, ən sɛvɹəl nɪɹbaɪ ɹufs. fəɹ ði il, kæmpɪŋ ɪn ə pleɪs wɑz ɪsɛnʃəli ðə seɪm θɪŋ əz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪt, əz ən il ɹɛstɪŋ wɑz əbaʊt twaɪs əz əlɝɾ əz ə ɹɛɡjəlɝ soʊlʒɝ ɑn pətʃɹoʊl. ɹænd hæd lɛf ðə lɑɹdʒɝ bʌlk ə hɪz fɔɹs aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi; hi wəd liv ɪt tə dɑbɹeɪn ən ɪz stuɝdz tə faɪn kɔɹɾɝz fəɹ ɹændz mɛn wɪðɪn ðə wɔlz.

The destination was easy to pick out; about five hundred Cairhienin armsmen were camped on the grounds of a spacious, stately mansion. Aiel also had tents on the grounds - but they had also claimed nearby buildings, and several nearby roofs. For the Aiel, camping in a place was essentially the same thing as guarding it, as an Aiel resting was about twice as alert as a regular soldier on patrol. Rand had left the larger bulk of his force outside the city; he would leave it to Dobraine and his stewards to find quarters for Rand's men within the walls.

ɹænd hɔltəd teɪdeɪʃɝ, ðən sɝveɪɾ ɪz nu hoʊm.

Rand halted Tai'daishar, then surveyed his new home.

wɪv noʊ hoʊm, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. wi dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪt. bɝn ɪɾ əweɪ, mɛltəd tə slæɡ, laɪk sæn ɪn ə faɪɝ.

We have no home, Lews Therin whispered. We destroyed it. Burned it away, melted to slag, like sand in a fire.

ðə mænʃən wɑz sɝɾənli ə stɛp ʌp fɹəm ðə moʊsli lɔɡ mænɝ. ɪts lɑɹdʒ ɡɹaʊnz wɝ bɔɹɾɝd baɪ aɪɝn ɡeɪts. ðə flaʊɝ bɛdz wɝ ɛmpti - flaʊɝz wɝ hɛzɪɾənt tə blum ðɪs spɹɪŋ - bʌt ðə lɔn wɑz ɡɹinɝ ðən moʊst i hæd sin. oʊ, ɪt wɑz moʊsli jɛloʊ ən bɹaʊn, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ pætʃəz ʌv ɡɹin. ðə ɡɹaʊndskipɝz wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ vɛɹi hɑɹd, ðɛɹ ɛfɝts ɔlsoʊ mænəfɛst ɪn ðə ɹoʊz ʌv ɛɹɪθ juz kʌɾ ɪn ðə ʃeɪps ə fænsɪfəl ænəməlz ət ðə saɪdz ə ðə lɔn.

The mansion was certainly a step up from the mostly log manor. Its large grounds were bordered by iron gates. The flower beds were empty - flowers were hesitant to bloom this spring - but the lawn was greener than most he had seen. Oh, it was mostly yellow and brown, but there were patches of green. The groundskeepers were trying very hard, their efforts also manifest in the rows of Aryth yews cut in the shapes of fanciful animals at the sides of the lawn.

ðə mænʃən ɪtsɛlf wɑz nɪɹli ə pæləs; ðəɹ wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ʌv kɔɹs, bɪlɔŋɪŋ tə ðə kɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz sɛd tə bi ɪnfɪɹiɝ tə ðə hoʊmz ə ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns. ðə bænɝ flæpɪŋ tɔl ətɑp ðə mænɝ wɑz ə bɹɪljənt ɡoʊld ən blæk, ən ɪt pɹoʊkleɪm ðɪs tə bi ðə siɾ ə haʊs tʃædmɑɝ. pɝhæps ðɪs maɪləsɹ hæd sin ðə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ə ði ʌðɝz əz ən ɑpɝtunəɾi. ɪf soʊ, ði oʊnli ɹil ɑpɝtunəɾi ʃid ɡeɪnd wɑz ðə tʃæns tə bi teɪkən baɪ ɹænd.

The mansion itself was nearly a palace; there was one of those in the city, of course, belonging to the king. But it was said to be inferior to the homes of the Council of Merchants. The banner flapping tall atop the manor was of brilliant gold and black, and it proclaimed this to be the seat of House Chadmar. Perhaps this Milisair had seen the departure of the others as an opportunity. If so, the only real opportunity she'd gained was the chance to be taken by Rand.

ðə ɡeɪts tə ðə mænʃən ɡɹaʊnz wɝ oʊpən, ən ði il ɪn ɪz ɑntʊɹɑʒ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi hɝiɪŋ ɪn, dʒɔɪnɪŋ klʌstɝz ə səsaɪəɾi əɹ klæn mɛmbɝz. ɪt wɑz ɝksəm ðət ðeɪ ɹɛɹli weɪɾəd ɑn ɹændz kəmænz əɹ ɔɹɾɝz, bʌɾ il wɝ il. ɛni sədʒɛstʃən ðət ðeɪ ʃəd weɪt wɑz sɪmpli mɛt wɪð læftɝ, əz ɪf i hæd meɪɾ ə ɡɹæn dʒoʊk. ɪt wəd bi iziɝ tə teɪm ðə wɪn ɪtsɛlf ðən tə ɡɛɾ əm tə bɪheɪv laɪk wɛtləndɝz.

The gates to the mansion grounds were open, and the Aiel in his entourage were already hurrying in, joining clusters of society or clan members. It was irksome that they rarely waited on Rand's commands or orders, but Aiel were Aiel. Any suggestion that they should wait was simply met with laughter, as if he had made a grand joke. It would be easier to tame the wind itself than to get them to behave like wetlanders.

ðət meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ʌv eɪvinhə. wɛɹ hæd ʃi ɡɔn, soʊ sʌɾənli? hi kəd fil əɹ θɹu ðə bɑnd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz feɪnt - ʃi wɑz vɛɹi fɑɹ əweɪ. tə ði ist. wʌt bɪznəs wɑz ðəɹ fəɹ əɹ ɪn ðə weɪst?

That made him think of Aviendha. Where had she gone, so suddenly? He could feel her through the bond, but it was faint - she was very far away. To the east. What business was there for her in the Waste?

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ɔl wɪmən wɝ dɪfəkəl tə ʌndɝstænd, ən ən il wʊmən wɑz tɛnfoʊl mɔɹ ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl. hi hæd hoʊp ðəɾ i wəd bi eɪbəl tə spɛn səm taɪm wɪð hɝ, bʌt ʃid pɔɪntɪdli əvɔɪɾəd hɪm. wɛl, pɝhæps ɪt wɑz mɪnz pɹɛzəns ðət kɛpt əɹ əweɪ. pɝhæps i wəd bi eɪbəl tə kip hɪmsɛlf fɹəm hɝɾɪŋ əɹ bɪfɔɹ dɛθ keɪm. bɛɾɝ ðəɾ eɪvinhə flɛd. hɪz ɛnəmiz dɪdnt noʊ ʌv əɹ jɛt.

He shook his head. All women were difficult to understand, and an Aiel woman was tenfold more incomprehensible. He had hoped that he would be able to spend some time with her, but she'd pointedly avoided him. Well, perhaps it was Min's presence that kept her away. Perhaps he would be able to keep himself from hurting her before death came. Better that Aviendha fled. His enemies didn't know of her yet.

hi ɝdʒ teɪdeɪʃɝ θɹu ðə ɡeɪts, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp ðə dʒɹaɪv tə ðə mænɝ haʊs ɪtsɛlf. hi dɪsmaʊntɪd, plʌkɪŋ ðə stætʃuɛt fɹəm ɪts stʃɹæp ən slaɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə ði oʊvɝsaɪz pɑkəɾ ə hɪz koʊt, wɪtʃ hæd bɪn kwɪkli teɪlɝd tə hoʊld ɪt. hi hændəɾ ɪz maʊn ɔf tə ə ɡɹum - wʌn ə ðə mænɝ haʊsəz oʊn sɝvəns, wɛɹɪŋ ə koʊɾ ʌv ɡɹin wɪð ə bɹaɪt waɪt ʃɝt bɪniθ, ðə kɑlɝ ən kʌfs ɹʌfəld. ðə mænɝz sɝvəns hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn əpɹaɪz ðət ɹænd wəd bi juzɪŋ ðə pleɪs əz ɪz oʊn, naʊ ðəɾ ɪts fɔɹmɝ ɑkjəpən hæd bɪn . . . ɡɪvən ɪz pɹətɛkʃən.

He urged Tai'daishar through the gates, riding up the drive to the manor house itself. He dismounted, plucking the statuette from its strap and sliding it into the oversized pocket of his coat, which had been quickly tailored to hold it. He handed his mount off to a groom - one of the manor house's own servants, wearing a coat of green with a bright white shirt beneath, the collar and cuffs ruffled. The manor's servants had already been apprised that Rand would be using the place as his own, now that its former occupant had been . . . given his protection.

dɑbɹeɪn dʒɔɪn ɪm əz i stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp ðə stɛps tə ðə bɪldɪŋ. ɪt wɑz wɑʃt ə kɹɪsp waɪt, wɪð wʊɾən pɪlɝz laɪnɪŋ ðə fɹʌn lændɪŋ. hi stɛpt ɪnsaɪd ðə fɹʌn dɔɹz. æftɝ lɪvɪŋ ɪn sɛvɹəl pæləsəz, hi wɑz stɪl ɪmpɹɛst. ən dɪsɡʌstəd. ði ɑpjələns i faʊn bɪɑn ðə mænɝz fɹʌn dɔɹz wəd nɛvɝ əv ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət ðə pipəl ə ðə sɪɾi stɑɹvd. ə laɪn ə vɛɹi nɝvəs sɝvəns stʊɾ ɪn ə ɹoʊ əlɔŋ ðə bæk ə ði ɛntʃɹɪweɪ. hi kəd sɛns ðɛɹ fɪɹ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɛvɹi deɪ ðət wʌnz dwɛlɪŋ wɑz ænɛks baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf.

Dobraine joined him as he strode up the steps to the building. It was washed a crisp white, with wooden pillars lining the front landing. He stepped inside the front doors. After living in several palaces, he was still impressed. And disgusted. The opulence he found beyond the manor's front doors would never have indicated that the people of the city starved. A line of very nervous servants stood in a row along the back of the entryway. He could sense their fear. It was not every day that one's dwelling was annexed by the Dragon Reborn himself.

ɹænd pʊld ɔf ɪz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌv baɪ tʌkɪŋ ɪz hæn bɪtwin ɪz ɑɹm ən ɪz saɪd, ðən slɪp ðə ɡlʌv ɪn ɪz bɛlt. "wɛɹ ɪz ʃi?" hi æskt, tɝnɪŋ tə ðə pɛɹ ə meɪɾənz - bɛɹælnə ən ɹaɪəlɪn  - hu wɝ kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ðə sɝvəns.

Rand pulled off his riding glove by tucking his hand between his arm and his side, then slipped the glove in his belt. "Where is she?" he asked, turning to the pair of Maidens - Beralna and Riallin  - who were keeping an eye on the servants.

"sɛkən flɔɹ," wʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz sɛd. "sɪpɪŋ ti waɪl əɹ hænd ʃeɪks soʊ mʌtʃ ɪt θɹɛɾənz tə bɹeɪk ðə pɔɹsələn."

"Second floor," one of the Maidens said. "Sipping tea while her hand shakes so much it threatens to break the porcelain."

"wi kip tɛlɪŋ əɹ ʃiz nɑɾ ə pɹɪznɝ," ði ʌðɝ meɪɾən sɛd. "ʃi dʒʌs kæn liv."

"We keep telling her she's not a prisoner," the other Maiden said. "She just can't leave."

boʊθ ə ðɛm faʊn ðəɾ əmjuzɪŋ. ɹænd ɡlæns tə ðə saɪɾ əz ɹəɑɹk dʒɔɪn ɪm ɪn ði ɛntʃɹɪweɪ.

Both of them found that amusing. Rand glanced to the side as Rhuarc joined him in the entryway.

ðə tɔl, faɪɝ-hɛɹd klæn tʃif ɪnspɛktɪd ðə ɹum, wɪð ɪts twɪŋkəlɪŋ ʃændəlɪɹ ən ɔɹnəmɛntɪd veɪsəz. ɹænd nu wʌɾ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. "ju meɪ teɪk ðə fɪfθ," hi sɛd. "bʌɾ oʊnli fɹəm ðə ɹɪtʃ u lɪv ɪn ðɪs dɪstʃɹɪkt."

The tall, fire-haired clan chief inspected the room, with its twinkling chandelier and ornamented vases. Rand knew what he was thinking. "You may take the fifth," he said. "But only from the rich who live in this district."

ðət wɑzn haʊ ɪt wɑz dʌn; ði il ʃʊɾə bɪn əlaʊd ðə fɪfθ fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn. bʌt ɹəɑɹk dɪd nɑɾ ɑɹɡju. wʌt ði il hæd dʌn ɪn teɪkɪŋ bændɑɹ ɛbən hædn ɹɪli bɪn ə tʃɹu kɑŋkwɛst, ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd fɔt ɡæŋz ən θʌɡz. pɝhæps i ʃʊdn əv ɡɪvən əm ɛniθɪŋ. bʌt kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə mæntʃənz laɪk ðɪs wʌn, ðəɹ wɑz wɛlθ tə spɛɹ fəɹ ði il hɪɹ, əmʌŋ ðə wɛlθi ət list.

That wasn't how it was done; the Aiel should have been allowed the fifth from everyone. But Rhuarc did not argue. What the Aiel had done in taking Bandar Eban hadn't really been a true conquest, though they had fought gangs and thugs. Perhaps he shouldn't have given them anything. But considering the mansions like this one, there was wealth to spare for the Aiel here, among the wealthy at least.

ðə meɪɾənz nɑɾəd, əz ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt, ðən loʊpt ɔf, pɹɑbli tə bɪɡɪn səlɛktɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃɛɹ. dɑbɹeɪn wɑtʃt əm wɪð kɑnstɝneɪʃən. kɛɹhin hæd sʌfɝd ði il fɪfθ ɑn sɛvɹəl əkeɪʒənz.

The Maidens nodded, as if they had expected it, then loped off, probably to begin selecting their share. Dobraine watched them with consternation. Cairhien had suffered the Aiel fifth on several occasions.

"aɪ nɛvɝ kən ʌndɝstænd waɪ jə lɛɾ əm plʌndɝ laɪk haɪweɪmɪn u faɪn ðə kæɹəvæn ɡɑɹdz əslip," kɔɹəl sɛd, swipɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum wɪð ə smaɪl. ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ði ɪmpɹɛsɪv fɝnɪʃɪŋz. "æn sətʃ ə pɹɪɾi pleɪs əz ðɪs. laɪk lɛɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝz tʃɹæmpəl spɹɪŋ bʌdz, ɪzən ɪt?"

"I never can understand why you let them plunder like highwaymen who find the caravan guards asleep," Corele said, sweeping into the room with a smile. She raised an eyebrow at the impressive furnishings. "And such a pretty place as this. Like letting soldiers trample spring buds, isn't it?"

hæd ʃi bɪn sɛn tə dil wɪð ɪm naʊ ðət hid ʃeɪkən mɛɹaɪs? ʃi mɛt ɹændz ɡeɪz ɪn əɹ plɛzənt weɪ, bʌɾ i hɛld ɪɾ əntɪl ʃi bɹoʊk ən tɝn əweɪ. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ə taɪm wən ðət hæd nɛvɝ wɝkt wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Had she been sent to deal with him now that he'd shaken Merise? She met Rand's gaze in her pleasant way, but he held it until she broke and turned away. He could remember a time when that had never worked with Aes Sedai.

hi tɝn tə dɑbɹeɪn. "ju hæv dʌn wɛl hɪɹ," hi sɛd tə ðə lɔɹd. "ivən ɪf jə hævən bɹɔɾ ɔɹɾɝ əz waɪdli əz aɪ wɪʃ. ɡæðɝ jəɹ ɑɹmmɪn. nɛɹɪʃmə hæz bɪn ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə pɹəvaɪɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ jə tə tɛɹ."

He turned to Dobraine. "You have done well here," he said to the lord. "Even if you haven't brought order as widely as I wish. Gather your armsmen. Narishma has been instructed to provide a gateway for you to Tear."

"tɛɹ, maɪ lɔɹd?" dɑbɹeɪn æskt, sɝpɹaɪzd.

"Tear, my Lord?" Dobraine asked, surprised.

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd. "tɛl dɑɹlɪn tə stɑp pɛstɝɪŋ mi wɪð mɛsənʒɝz. hiz tə kip ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz fɔɹsɪz; əl bɹɪŋ ɪm tə ɑɹæd dumən wən aɪ dɪsaɪd ðə taɪm ɪz ɹaɪt." ðət wəd bi æftɝ i mɛt wɪð ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz, wɪtʃ miɾɪŋ wəd dətɝmən mʌtʃ.

"Yes," Rand said. "Tell Darlin to stop pestering me with messengers. He is to keep gathering his forces; I'll bring him to Arad Doman when I decide the time is right." That would be after he met with the Daughter of the Nine Moons, which meeting would determine much.

dɑbɹeɪn lʊk feɪnli kɹɛstfɔlən. əɹ wɑz ðət dʒʌst ɹændz ɪntɝpɹɪteɪʃən? dɑbɹeɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɹɛɹli tʃeɪnʒd. wɑz i ɪmædʒənɪŋ ɪz hoʊps ə ðɪs kɪŋdəm wɪðɝɪŋ əweɪ? wɑz i plɑɾɪŋ əɡɛnst ɹænd? "jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ əsum aɪm tə liv ɪmiɾiətli?"

Dobraine looked faintly crestfallen. Or was that just Rand's interpretation? Dobraine's expression rarely changed. Was he imagining his hopes of this kingdom withering away? Was he plotting against Rand? "Yes, my Lord. I assume I'm to leave immediately?"

dɑbɹeɪn əz nɛvɝ ɡɪvən əs ɹizən tə daʊt hɪm. hi ivən ɡæðɝd səpɔɹt fəɹ ɪleɪn tə teɪk ðə sʌn θɹoʊn!

Dobraine has never given us reason to doubt him. He even gathered support for Elayne to take the Sun Throne!

ɹænd hæd bɪn əweɪ fɹəm ɪm tu lɔŋ. tu lɔŋ tə tʃɹʌs hɪm. bʌt bɛs tə ɡɛɾ ɪm aʊt fəɹ naʊ;

Rand had been away from him too long. Too long to trust him. But best to get him out for now;

hid hæd tu mʌtʃ taɪm tə ɡɛɾ ə fʊthoʊl hɪɹ, ən ɹænd dɪdn tʃɹʌst ɛni kɛɹhinɪn tə əvɔɪd ɡeɪmz wɪð pɑlətɪks.

he'd had too much time to get a foothold here, and Rand didn't trust any Cairhienin to avoid games with politics.

"jɛs, jə liv wɪðɪn ði aʊɝ," ɹænd sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə wɔk ʌp ðə ɡɹeɪsfəl waɪt stɛɹz.

"Yes, you leave within the hour," Rand said, turning to walk up the graceful white stairs.

dɑbɹeɪn səluɾəd, stoʊɪk əz ɔlweɪz, ən lɛft aʊt ðə fɹʌn dɔɹweɪ. hi oʊbeɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli. noʊ wɝɾ ə kəmpleɪnt. hi wɑz ə ɡʊd mæn. ɹænd nu hi wɑz.

Dobraine saluted, stoic as always, and left out the front doorway. He obeyed immediately. No word of complaint. He was a good man. Rand knew he was.

laɪt, wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ tə mi? ɹænd θɔt. aɪ nid tə tʃɹʌst səm pipəl. doʊn aɪ?

Light, what is happening to me? Rand thought. I need to trust some people. Don't I?

tʃɹʌst . . . ? luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. jɛs, pɝhæps wi kən tʃɹʌs hɪm. hi kænɑt tʃænəl. laɪt, ðə wʌn wi kæn tʃɹʌst əɾ ɔl ɪz aʊɝsɛlvz. . . .

Trust . . . ? Lews Therin whispered. Yes, perhaps we can trust him. He cannot channel. Light, the one we can't trust at all is ourselves. . . .

ɹænd klɛntʃt ɪz dʒɔ. hi wəd ɹɪwɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn wɪð ðə kɪŋdəm ɪf ælsələm kʊdn bi faʊnd. ɪɾɝɑldi dɪdnt wɑn ɪt.

Rand clenched his jaw. He would reward Dobraine with the kingdom if Alsalam couldn't be found. Ituralde didn't want it.

ðə stɛɹz ɹoʊz stʃɹeɪɾ ən bɹɔd tə ə lændɪŋ, ðən splɪɾ ən twɪstəɾ ʌp tə ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə lændɪŋ ðəɹ ɑn tu sɛpɹət saɪdz. "aɪ niɾ ən ɑɾiəns tʃeɪmbɝ," ɹænd sɛd tə ðə sɝvəns bɪloʊ, "æn ə θɹoʊn. kwɪkli."

The stairs rose straight and broad to a landing, then split and twisted up to the second floor, touching the landing there on two separate sides. "I need an audience chamber," Rand said to the servants below, "and a throne. Quickly."

lɛs ðən tɛn mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, ɹænd sæɾ ɪn ə plʌʃli dɛkɝeɪɾəd sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə mɝtʃən maɪləsɹ tʃædmɑɝ tə bi bɹɔt tə hɪm. hɪz ɔɹnətli kɑɹvd waɪt wʊd tʃɛɹ wɑzn kwaɪɾ ə θɹoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt wəd du. pɝhæps maɪləsɹ hæd juzd ɪt fəɹ ɑɾiənsəz hɝsɛlf. ðə ɹum dɪd sim leɪɾ aʊt laɪk ə θɹoʊn ɹum, wɪð ə ʃæloʊli ɹeɪz deɪz fəɹ ɪm tə sɪɾ ɑn. boʊθ deɪz ən flɔɹ bɪloʊ wɝ kʌvɝɾ ɪn ə tɛkstʃɝd ɡɹin ən ɹɛd ɹʌɡ ʌv fænsɪfəl dɪzaɪn wɪtʃ mætʃt ðə si foʊk pɔɹsələn ɑn pɛɾəstəlz ət ðə kɔɹnɝ. fɔɹ bɹɔd wɪndoʊz bɪhaɪn ɪm - itʃ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə wɔk θɹu - ʌʃɝɾ oʊvɝkæst sʌnlaɪɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum, ən ɪt fɛl ɑn ɪz bæk əz i sæɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ ən lin fɔɹwɝd, wʌn ɑɹm ɹɛstɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz niz. ðə fɪɡjɝin sæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ hɪm.

Less than ten minutes later, Rand sat in a plushly decorated sitting room on the second floor, waiting for the merchant Milisair Chadmar to be brought to him. His ornately carved white wood chair wasn't quite a throne, but it would do. Perhaps Milisair had used it for audiences herself. The room did seem laid out like a throne room, with a shallowly raised dais for him to sit on. Both dais and floor below were covered in a textured green and red rug of fanciful design which matched the Sea Folk porcelain on pedestals at the corner. Four broad windows behind him - each large enough to walk through - ushered overcast sunlight into the room, and it fell on his back as he sat in the chair and leaned forward, one arm resting across his knees. The figurine sat on the floor just before him.

ʃɔɹtli, maɪləsɹ tʃædmɑɝ wɔk θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ pæs ði il ɡɑɹdz. ʃi wɔɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz feɪməs dəmɑni dʒɹɛsəz. ɪt kʌvɝɾ əɹ bɑɾi fɹəm nɛk tə toʊ bʌt wɑz bɛɹli oʊpeɪk ən klʌŋ tə ɛvɹi kɝv - ʌv wɪtʃ ʃi hæd mɔɹ ðən əɹ fɛɹ ʃɛɹ. ðə dʒɹɛs wɑz ə dip ɡɹin, ən ʃi wɔɹ pɝlz əɾ əɹ nɛk. hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ, ɪn taɪt kɝlz, hʌŋ daʊn pæst əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, sɛvɹəl lɑks fɹeɪmɪŋ əɹ feɪs. hi hædn ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə bi soʊ jʌŋ, bɛɹli ɪndə hɝ θɝɾiz.

Shortly, Milisair Chadmar walked through the doorway past the Aiel guards. She wore one of those famous Domani dresses. It covered her body from neck to toe but was barely opaque and clung to every curve - of which she had more than her fair share. The dress was of deep green, and she wore pearls at her neck. Her dark hair, in tight curls, hung down past her shoulders, several locks framing her face. He hadn't expected her to be so young, barely into her thirties.

ɪt wəd bi ə ʃeɪm tə ɛksəkjut hɝ.

It would be a shame to execute her.

dʒʌst wʌn deɪ, hi θɔt tə hɪmsɛlf, ən ɔlɹɛɾi aɪ θɪŋk ʌv ɛksəkjuɾɪŋ ə wʊmən fəɹ nɑɾ əɡɹiɪŋ tə fɑloʊ mi. ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪm wən aɪ kəd bɛɹli stæn tə ɛksəkjut dɪzɝvɪŋ kɹɪmənəlz. bʌɾ i wəd də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn.

Just one day, he thought to himself, and already I think of executing a woman for not agreeing to follow me. There was a time when I could barely stand to execute deserving criminals. But he would do what must be done.

maɪləsɹz dip kɝtsi sim tə ɪmplaɪ ðət ʃi æksɛptɪɾ ɪz əθɔɹəɾi. əɹ pɝhæps ɪt wɑz sɪmpli ə minz ʌv əlaʊɪŋ ɪm ə bɛɾɝ vju ʌv wʌt ðə dʒɹɛs æksɛntʃəweɪɾɪd. ə vɛɹi dəmɑni θɪŋ tə du.

Milisair's deep curtsy seemed to imply that she accepted his authority. Or perhaps it was simply a means of allowing him a better view of what the dress accentuated. A very Domani thing to do.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli fəɹ hɝ, hi ɔlɹɛɾi hæd mɔɹ pɹɑbləmz wɪð wɪmən ðən i nu haʊ tə hændəl.

Unfortunately for her, he already had more problems with women than he knew how to handle.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," maɪləsɹ sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm əɹ kɝtsi. "haʊ meɪ aɪ sɝv ju?"

"My Lord Dragon," Milisair said, rising from her curtsy. "How may I serve you?"

"wɛn wɑz ðə læs kəmjunəkeɪʃən jə hæd fɹəm kɪŋ ælsələm?" ɹænd æskt. hi pɔɪntɪdli dɪdnt ɡɪv əɹ liv tə sɪɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə ɹumz tʃɛɹz.

"When was the last communication you had from King Alsalam?" Rand asked. He pointedly didn't give her leave to sit in one of the room's chairs.

"ðə kɪŋ?" ʃi æskt, sɝpɹaɪzd. "ɪɾ əz bɪn wiks naʊ."

"The King?" she asked, surprised. "It has been weeks now."

"aɪ wɪl nid tə spik tə ðə mɛsənʒɝ u bɹɔt ðə leɪɾəst mɛsədʒ," ɹænd sɛd.

"I will need to speak to the messenger who brought the latest message," Rand said.

"aɪ æm nɑt sɝɾən i kən bi faʊnd." ðə wʊmən saʊndəd flʌstɝd. "aɪ də nɑt kip tʃɹæk ə ðə kʌmɪŋ ən ɡoʊɪŋ ʌv ɛvɹi mɛsənʒɝ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, maɪ lɔɹd."

"I am not certain he can be found." The woman sounded flustered. "I do not keep track of the coming and going of every messenger in the city, my Lord."

ɹænd lin fɔɹwɝd. "du jə laɪ tə mi?" hi æsk sɔfli.

Rand leaned forward. "Do you lie to me?" he asked softly.

hɝ maʊθ oʊpənd, pɝhæps ɪn ʃɑk əɾ ɪz blʌntnəs. ðə dəmɑni wɝ noʊ kɛɹhinɪn - hu hæɾ ə simɪŋli ɪnbɔɹn pəlɪɾəkəl kɹæftinəs - bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ə sʌɾəl pipəl. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðə wɪmən.

Her mouth opened, perhaps in shock at his bluntness. The Domani were no Cairhienin - who had a seemingly inborn political craftiness - but they were a subtle people. Particularly the women.

ɹænd wɑz niðɝ sʌɾəl nɔɹ kɹæfti. hi wɑz ə ʃifɝɾɝ tɝn kɑŋkɝɝ, ən ɪz hɑɹt wɑz ðəɾ ʌv ə tu ɹɪvɝz mæn, ivən ɪf ɪz blʌd wɑz il. wʌtɛvɝ pɑlətɪkɪŋ ʃi wɑz juz tə pleɪɪŋ, ɪt wʊdnt wɝk ɑn hɪm. hi hæd noʊ peɪʃəns fəɹ ɡeɪmz.

Rand was neither subtle nor crafty. He was a sheepherder turned conqueror, and his heart was that of a Two Rivers man, even if his blood was Aiel. Whatever politicking she was used to playing, it wouldn't work on him. He had no patience for games.

"aɪ . . ." maɪləsɹ sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. . . ."

"I . . ." Milisair said, staring at him. "My Lord Dragon. . . ."

wʌt wɑz ʃi haɪɾɪŋ? "wʌt dɪd jə də wɪð hɪm?" ɹænd æskt, meɪkɪŋ ə ɡɛs. "ðə mɛsənʒɝ?"

What was she hiding? "What did you do with him?" Rand asked, making a guess. "The messenger?"

"hi nu nʌθɪŋ ə ðə kɪŋz loʊkeɪʃən," maɪləsɹ sɛd kwɪkli, ðə wɝdz simɪŋ tə spɪl fɹəm hɝ. "maɪ kwɛstʃənɝz wɝ kwaɪt θɝoʊ."

"He knew nothing of the King's location," Milisair said quickly, the words seeming to spill from her. "My questioners were quite thorough."

"hi ɪz dɛd?"

"He is dead?"

"aɪ. . . . noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən."

"I. . . . No, my Lord Dragon."

"ðɛn jəl əv ɪm bɹɔt tə mi."

"Then you will have him brought to me."

ʃi peɪl fɝðɝ, ən ɡlæns tə wʌn saɪd, pɝhæps ɹiflɛksɪvli sikɪŋ ɪskeɪp. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ʃi sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli, bɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ aɪz bæk tə hɪm. "naʊ ðət jə ɑɹ hɪɹ, pɝhæps ðə kɪŋ wɪl ɹɪmeɪn . . . hɪɾən. pɝhæps ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə sik ɪm aʊt fɝðɝ."

She paled further, and glanced to one side, perhaps reflexively seeking escape. "My Lord Dragon," she said hesitantly, bringing her eyes back to him. "Now that you are here, perhaps the King will remain . . . hidden. Perhaps there is no need to seek him out further."

ʃi θɪŋks hiz dɛd tu, ɹænd θɔt. ɪts meɪɾ əɹ teɪk ɹɪsks.

She thinks he's dead too, Rand thought. It has made her take risks.

"ðɛɹ ɪz nid tə faɪn ælsələm," ɹænd sɛd, "ɔɹ ət lis dɪskʌvɝ wʌt hæpən tə hɪm. wi nid tə noʊ hɪz feɪt soʊ ðət jə kən tʃuz ə nu kɪŋ. ðəɾ ɪz haʊ ɪt hæpənz, kɝɛkt?"

"There is need to find Alsalam," Rand said, "or at least discover what happened to him. We need to know his fate so that you can choose a new king. That is how it happens, correct?"

"aɪm sɝɾən jə kən bi kɹaʊn kwɪkli, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ʃi sɛd smuðli.

"I'm certain you can be crowned quickly, my Lord Dragon," she said smoothly.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt bi kɪŋ hɪɹ," ɹænd sɛd. "bɹɪŋ mi ðə mɛsənʒɝ, maɪləsɹ, ən pɝhæps jəl lɪv tə si ə nu kɪŋ kɹaʊnd. jə ɑɹ dɪsmɪst."

"I will not be king here," Rand said. "Bring me the messenger, Milisair, and perhaps you will live to see a new king crowned. You are dismissed."

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən kɝtsiɾ əɡɛn ən wɪθdʒɹu. ɹænd kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə mɪn stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪd wɪð ði il, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mɝtʃən dɪpɑɹt. hi kɑɾ əɹ aɪz, ən ʃi lʊk tʃɹʌbəld. hæd ʃi sin ɛni vjuɪŋz əbaʊt maɪləsɹ? hi ɔlmoʊs kɔl tə hɝ, bʌt ʃi vænɪʃt, wɔkɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ə kwɪk stɛp. tə ðə saɪd, əliviə wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ wɪð kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. ðə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn hæd steɪɾ əluf ɹisənli, əz ɪf baɪɾɪŋ əɹ taɪm, weɪɾɪŋ əntɪl ʃi kəd fʊlfɪl əɹ dɛstəni ɪn hɛlpɪŋ ɹænd daɪ.

She hesitated, then curtsied again and withdrew. Rand caught a glimpse of Min standing outside with the Aiel, watching the merchant depart. He caught her eyes, and she looked troubled. Had she seen any viewings about Milisair? He almost called to her, but she vanished, walking away with a quick step. To the side, Alivia watched her go with curiosity. The former damane had stayed aloof recently, as if biding her time, waiting until she could fulfill her destiny in helping Rand die.

hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf stændɪŋ. ðət lʊk ɪn mɪnz aɪz. wɑz ʃi æŋɡɹi wɪð hɪm? wɑz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ɪz hæn əɾ əɹ nɛk, hɪz ni pɹɛsɪŋ əɹ əɡɛns ðə flɔɹ?

He found himself standing. That look in Min's eyes. Was she angry with him? Was she remembering his hand at her neck, his knee pressing her against the floor?

hi sæt bæk daʊn. mɪn kəd weɪt. "ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd, ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ði il. "bɹɪŋ mi maɪ skɹaɪbz ən stuɝdz, əlɔŋ wɪð ɹəɑɹk, beɪl ən wʌtɛvɝ sɪɾi wɝðiz hævən flɛd ðə sɪɾi əɹ bɪn kɪld ɪn ɹaɪəts. wi nid tə ɡoʊ oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹeɪn dɪstʃɹəbjuʃən plænz."

He sat back down. Min could wait. "All right," he said, addressing the Aiel. "Bring me my scribes and stewards, along with Rhuarc, Bael and whatever city worthies haven't fled the city or been killed in riots. We need to go over the grain distribution plans."

ði il sɛn ɹʌnɝz ən ɹænd sɛɾəld bæk ɪndə hɪz tʃɛɹ. hi wəd si ðə pipəl fɛd, ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ ən ɡæðɝ ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns. hi wəɾ ivən si ðəɾ ə nu kɪŋ wɑz tʃoʊzən.

The Aiel sent runners and Rand settled back into his chair. He would see the people fed, restore order and gather the Council of Merchants. He would even see that a new king was chosen.

bʌɾ i wəɾ ɔlsoʊ faɪn aʊt wɛɹ ælsələm hæd ɡɔn. fəɹ ðɛɹ, hɪz ɪnstɪŋks sɛd, wɑz ðə bɛs pleɪs tə faɪnd ɡɹeɪndəl. ɪt wɑz ɪz bɛs lɛd.

But he would also find out where Alsalam had gone. For there, his instincts said, was the best place to find Graendal. It was his best lead.

ɪf i dɪd faɪn hɝ, hi wəd si ðət ʃi daɪd baɪ bɑlfaɪɝ, dʒʌs laɪk sɛmɝhɪdʒ. hi wəd də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn.

If he did find her, he would see that she died by balefire, just like Semirhage. He would do what must be done.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾi

CHAPTER 30

oʊld ædvaɪs ɡɔɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd vɛɹi lɪɾəl ə hɪz fɑðɝ - ðə mæn hæd nɛvɝ bɪn mʌtʃ ʌv ə fɑðɝ, tə hɪm ət list - bʌɾ i dɪɾ əv ə stʃɹɔŋ mɛmɹi ʌv ə deɪ ɪn ðə keɪɛmlɪn pæləs ɡɑɹɾənz. ɡɔɪn hæd bɪn stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl pɑnd, pɪtʃɪŋ pɛbəlz ɪndə ɪt. tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl hæd wɔk pæs daʊn ðə ɹoʊz mɑɹtʃ, jʌŋ ɡɑləɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd.

Old Advice Gawyn remembered very little of his father - the man had never been much of a father, to him at least - but he did have a strong memory of a day in the Caemlyn palace gardens. Gawyn had been standing beside a small pond, pitching pebbles into it. Taringail had walked past down the Rose March, young Galad at his side.

ðə sin wɑz stɪl vɪvəɾ ɪn ɡɔɪnz maɪnd. ðə hɛvi sɛn ə ðə ɹoʊzɪz ɪn fʊl blum. ðə sɪlvɝ ɹɪpəlz ɑn ðə pɑnd, ðə mɪnoʊz skæɾɝɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə mɪniətʃʊɹ boʊldɝ hid dʒʌs tɔst ət ðɛm.

The scene was still vivid in Gawyn's mind. The heavy scent of the roses in full bloom. The silver ripples on the pond, the minnows scattering away from the miniature boulder he'd just tossed at them.

hi kəd pɪktʃɝ ɪz fɑðɝ wɛl. tɔl, hænsəm, hɛɹ wɪð ə slaɪt weɪv tə ɪt. ɡɑləd hæd bɪn stʃɹeɪt-bækt ən sɑmbɝ ivən ðɛn. ə fju mʌnθs leɪɾɝ, ɡɑləd wəd ɹɛskju ɡɔɪn fɹəm dʒɹaʊnɪŋ ɪn ðət vɛɹi pɑnd.

He could picture his father well. Tall, handsome, hair with a slight wave to it. Galad had been straight-backed and somber even then. A few months later, Galad would rescue Gawyn from drowning in that very pond.

ɡɔɪn kəd hɪɹ ɪz fɑðɝ spik wɝdz ðət hid nɛvɝ fɝɡɑɾən. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls wʌn θɔɾ ə tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹd, ðɪs bɪɾ ʌv ædvaɪs ɹæŋ tʃɹu. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ tu ɡɹups ə pipəl jə ʃəd nɛvɝ tʃɹʌst," ðə mæn hæd bɪn seɪɪŋ tə ɡɑləɾ əz ðeɪ pæst. "ðə fɝst ɑɹ pɹɪɾi wɪmən. ðə sɛkən ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. laɪt hɛlp ju, sʌn, ɪf jə ɛvɝ əv tə feɪs sʌmwʌn u ɪz boʊθ."

Gawyn could hear his father speak words that he'd never forgotten. Whatever else one thought of Taringail Damodred, this bit of advice rang true. "There are two groups of people you should never trust," the man had been saying to Galad as they passed. "The first are pretty women. The second are Aes Sedai. Light help you, son, if you ever have to face someone who is both."

laɪt hɛlp ju, sʌn.

Light help you, son.

"aɪ sɪmpli kænɑt si dɪsəbɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɪkspɹɛs wɪl ɪn ðɪs mæɾɝ," ləleɪn sɛd pɹɪmli, stɝɪŋ ɪŋk ɪn ðə smɔl dʒɑɹ ɑn əɹ dɛsk. noʊ mæn tʃɹʌstɪd bjuɾəfəl wɪmən, fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ fæsəneɪʃən wɪð ðɛm. bʌt fju ɹilaɪzd wʌt tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl hæd sɛd - ðəɾ ə pɹɪɾi ɡɝl, laɪk ə koʊl ðət hæd kul dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lʊk hɑt, kəd bi fɑɹ, fɑɹ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs.

"I simply cannot see disobeying the Amyrlin's express will in this matter," Lelaine said primly, stirring ink in the small jar on her desk. No man trusted beautiful women, for all their fascination with them. But few realized what Taringail had said - that a pretty girl, like a coal that had cooled just enough to no longer look hot, could be far, far more dangerous.

ləleɪn wɑzn bjuɾəfəl, bʌt ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən ʃi smaɪld. slɛndɝ ən ɡɹeɪsfəl, wɪθaʊɾ ə spɛk ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ, ən ɑmən feɪs wɪð fʊl lɪps. ʃi lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm wɪð aɪz ðət wɝ fɑɹ tu kʌmli tə bɪlɔŋ tə ə wʊmən ə hɝ kɹæftinəs. ən ʃi sim tə noʊ. ʃi ʌndɝstʊd ðət ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ətʃɹæktɪv ɪnʌf tə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən, bʌt nɑt stʌnɪŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk mɛn wɛɹi.

Lelaine wasn't beautiful, but she was pretty, particularly when she smiled. Slender and graceful, without a speck of gray in her dark hair, an almond face with full lips. She looked up at him with eyes that were far too comely to belong to a woman of her craftiness. And she seemed to know. She understood that she was just attractive enough to draw attention, but not stunning enough to make men wary.

ʃi wɑz ə wʊmən ə ðə moʊs deɪnʒɝəs taɪp. wʌn u fɛlt ɹil, hu meɪd mɛn θɪŋk ðeɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə hoʊld əɹ ətɛnʃən. ʃi wɑzn pɹɪɾi laɪk ɛɡwin, hu meɪd jə wɑnə spɛn taɪm wɪð hɝ. ðɪs wʊmənz smaɪl meɪd jə wɑnə kaʊn ðə naɪvz ɑn jəɹ bɛlt ən ɪn jəɹ but, dʒʌs tə meɪk ʃʊɹ nʌn ə ðɛm hæd faʊn ðɛɹ weɪ ɪndə jəɹ bæk waɪl jə wɝ dɪstʃɹæktəd.

She was a woman of the most dangerous type. One who felt real, who made men think they might be able to hold her attention. She wasn't pretty like Egwene, who made you want to spend time with her. This woman's smile made you want to count the knives on your belt and in your boot, just to make sure none of them had found their way into your back while you were distracted.

ɡɔɪn stʊd bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, ʃeɪɾɪd baɪ ðə stʃɹeɪt-tɑp blu tɛnt. hi hædn bɪn ɪnvaɪɾəd tə sɪt, ən i hæd nɑɾ æsk fəɹ ðə pɹɪvlədʒ. tɔkɪŋ tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt wʌn, ɹikwaɪɝd wɪts ən səbɹaɪəɾi. hid ɹæðɝ stænd. pɝhæps ɪt wəd kip ɪm mɔɹ əlɝt.

Gawyn stood beside her writing table, shaded by the straight-topped blue tent. He hadn't been invited to sit, and he had not asked for the privilege. Talking to an Aes Sedai, particularly an important one, required wits and sobriety. He'd rather stand. Perhaps it would keep him more alert.

"ɛɡwin ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹətɛk ju," ɡɔɪn sɛd, kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɪz fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. "ðæts waɪ ʃi kəmændəd jə tə fɔɹɡoʊ ə ɹɛskju. ʃi ɑbviəsli dʌznt wɑn jə tə ɹɪsk jʊɹsɛlvz. ʃiz sɛlf- sækɹəfaɪsɪŋ tə ə fɔlt." ɪf ʃi wɝnt, hi æɾəd ɪn ɪz maɪnd, ʃid nɛvɝ əv lɛt jə ɔl bʊli hɝ ɪndə pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

"Egwene is trying to protect you," Gawyn said, controlling his frustration. "That's why she commanded you to forgo a rescue. She obviously doesn't want you to risk yourselves. She is self- sacrificing to a fault." If she weren't, he added in his mind, she'd never have let you all bully her into pretending to be the Amyrlin Seat.

"ʃi simz vɛɹi kɑnfəɾənt ə hɝ seɪfti," ləleɪn sɛd, dɪpɪŋ əɹ pɛn ɪndə ði ɪŋk. ʃi bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪɾ ɑn ə pis ə pɑɹtʃmənt; ə noʊt tə sʌmwʌn. ɡɔɪn pəlaɪtli dɪdn ɹɛɾ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ðoʊ hi dɪd noʊɾəs ðə kælkjəleɪɾəd muv ɑn əɹ pɑɹt. hi wɑz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf ðəɾ i kʊdn dɪmæn əɹ fʊl ətɛnʃən. hi tʃoʊz nɑt tə æknɑlɪdʒ ði ɪnsəlt. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bʊli bɹaɪn hædnt wɝkt; ɪt wəd bi ivən lɛs ɪfɛktɪv wɪð ðɪs wʊmən.

"She seems very confident of her safety," Lelaine said, dipping her pen into the ink. She began to write on a piece of parchment; a note to someone. Gawyn politely didn't read over her shoulder, though he did notice the calculated move on her part. He was unimportant enough that he couldn't demand her full attention. He chose not to acknowledge the insult. Trying to bully Bryne hadn't worked; it would be even less effective with this woman.

"ʃiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊt jəɹ wɝiz əɾ iz, ləleɪn sədaɪ," hi sɛɾ ɪnstɛd.

"She's trying to put your worries at ease, Lelaine Sedai," he said instead.

"aɪ æm ə fɛɹ dʒʌdʒ ə pipəl, jʌŋ tʃɹəkənd. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ʃi filz ʃiz ɪn deɪnʒɝ." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. hɝ pɝfjum smɛld ʌv æpəl blɑsəmz.

"I am a fair judge of people, young Trakand. I do not think she feels she is in danger." She shook her head. Her perfume smelled of apple blossoms.

"aɪ də nɑt daʊt ju," hi ɹɪplaɪd. "bʌt pɝhæps ɪf aɪ nu haʊ ɪts jə kəmjunəkeɪt wɪð hɝ, aɪ kəd dʒʌdʒ bɛɾɝ. ɪf aɪ kəd - "

"I do not doubt you," he replied. "But perhaps if I knew how it is you communicate with her, I could judge better. If I could - "

"ju hæv bɪn wɔɹnd nɑt tə æsk əbaʊt ðæt, tʃaɪld," ləleɪn sɛɾ ɪn əɹ sɑft, məloʊɾiəs vɔɪs.

"You have been warned not to ask about that, child," Lelaine said in her soft, melodious voice.

"liv θɪŋz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Leave things of the Aes Sedai to the Aes Sedai."

vɝtʃuəli ðə seɪm ænsɝ itʃ sɪstɝ ɡeɪv wən i æsk haʊ ðeɪ kəmjunəkeɪɾɪd wɪð ɛɡwin.

Virtually the same answer each sister gave when he asked how they communicated with Egwene.

hi klɛntʃt ɪz dʒɔ ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. wʌt hæɾ i ɪkspɛktəd? ɪɾ ɪnvɑlv juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. æftɝ ɔl ɪz taɪm ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, hi stɪl hæd lɪɾəl aɪdiə ʌv wʌt ðə paʊɝ kəɾ ən kʊdn du.

He clenched his jaw in frustration. What had he expected? It involved using the One Power. After all his time in the White Tower, he still had little idea of what the Power could and couldn't do.

"ɹəɡɑɹdləs," ləleɪn kəntɪnjud, "ði æmɪɝlɪn θɪŋks hɝsɛlf kwaɪt seɪf. wʌt wiv dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ʃimɹɪnz stɔɹi oʊnli ɹiɪnfɔɹsɪz ən kɝɔbɝeɪts wʌɾ ɛɡwin əz toʊld ʌs. ɪleɪɾə ɪz soʊ mæd wɪð paʊɝ ðət ʃi dʌzn kənsɪɾɝ ðə ɹaɪtfəl æmɪɝlɪn ə θɹɛt."

"Regardless," Lelaine continued, "the Amyrlin thinks herself quite safe. What we've discovered in Shemerin's story only reinforces and corroborates what Egwene has told us. Elaida is so mad with power that she doesn't consider the rightful Amyrlin a threat."

ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ʃi wɑzn seɪɪŋ. ɡɔɪn kəd tɛl ɪt. hi kəd nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ə stʃɹeɪɾ ænsɝ fɹəm əm ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ wʌɾ ɛɡwinz stæɾəs wɑz kɝənli. hid hɝd ɹumɝz ðət ʃid bɪn ɪmpɹɪzənd, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əlaʊd tə ɹoʊm fɹi əz ə nɑvəs. bʌt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz əbaʊɾ əz izi əz tʃɝnɪŋ ɹɑks ɪndə bʌɾɝ!

There was more she wasn't saying. Gawyn could tell it. He could never get a straight answer from them regarding what Egwene's status was currently. He'd heard rumors that she'd been imprisoned, no longer allowed to roam free as a novice. But getting information from an Aes Sedai was about as easy as churning rocks into butter!

ɡɔɪn tʊk ə bɹɛθ. hi kʊdn luz ɪz tɛmpɝ. ɪf i dɪd ðæt, hid nɛvɝ ɡɛt ləleɪn tə lɪsən.

Gawyn took a breath. He couldn't lose his temper. If he did that, he'd never get Lelaine to listen.

ən i niɾəd hɝ. bɹaɪn wʊdn muv wɪθaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔθɝəzeɪʃən, ən əz fɑɹ əz ɡɔɪn hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə tɛl, hɪz bɛs tʃænsəz ʌv ɡeɪnɪŋ ɪt keɪm fɹəm ləleɪn əɹ ɹoʊmændə. ɛvɹiwʌn sim tə lɪsən tə wʌn ə ðə tu əɹ ði ʌðɝ.

And he needed her. Bryne wouldn't move without Aes Sedai authorization, and as far as Gawyn had been able to tell, his best chances of gaining it came from Lelaine or Romanda. Everyone seemed to listen to one of the two or the other.

fɔɹtʃənətli, ɡɔɪn hæd faʊn ðəɾ i kəd pleɪ ðɛm ɔf wʌn ənʌðɝ. ə vɪzət tə ɹoʊmændə ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz pɹɑmptəɾ ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən fɹəm ləleɪn. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə ɹizən ðeɪ wɝ iɡɝ tə si hɪm ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs hæd vɛɹi lɪɾəl tə də wɪð ɛɡwin. noʊ daʊt ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən wəd muv ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən vɛɹi sun.

Fortunately, Gawyn had found that he could play them off one another. A visit to Romanda almost always prompted an invitation from Lelaine. Of course, the reason they were eager to see him in the first place had very little to do with Egwene. No doubt the conversation would move in that direction very soon.

"pɝhæps jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt, ləleɪn sədaɪ," hi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ ə dɪfɹən tæk. "pɝhæps ɛɡwin dʌz bɪliv hɝsɛlf tə bi seɪf. bʌɾ ɪzən ðəɹ ə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət ʃiz ɹɔŋ? jə kæn ɑnəsli bɪliv ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wɪl lɛɾ ə wʊmən u kleɪm tə bi æmɪɝlɪn wɑndɝ ɝaʊn ðə waɪt taʊɝ fɹi? ðɪs ɪz ɑbviəsli dʒʌst ə minz ə ʃoʊɪŋ ɔf ə kæptʃɝd ɹaɪvəl bɪfɔɹ ɛksəkjuɾɪŋ hɝ."

"Perhaps you are right, Lelaine Sedai," he said, trying a different tack. "Perhaps Egwene does believe herself to be safe. But isn't there a possibility that she is wrong? You can't honestly believe that Elaida will let a woman who claimed to be Amyrlin wander around the White Tower free? This is obviously just a means of showing off a captured rival before executing her."

"pɝhæps," ləleɪn sɛd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə ɹaɪt. ʃi hæɾ ə floʊɪŋ, ɔɹneɪt hænd. "bʌt mʌst aɪ nɑɾ əphoʊl ði æmɪɝlɪn, ivən ɪf ʃiz mɪsɡaɪɾɪd?"

"Perhaps," Lelaine said, continuing to write. She had a flowing, ornate hand. "But must I not uphold the Amyrlin, even if she is misguided?"

ɡɔɪn ɡeɪv noʊ ɹɪspɑns. ʌv kɔɹs ʃi kəd dɪsəbeɪ ðə wɪl ə ði æmɪɝlɪn. hi nu ɪnʌf ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ pɑlətɪks tə ʌndɝstæn ɪt wɑz dʌn ɔl ðə taɪm. bʌt seɪɪŋ ðət wəɾ əkɑmplɪʃ nʌθɪŋ.

Gawyn gave no response. Of course she could disobey the will of the Amyrlin. He knew enough of Aes Sedai politics to understand it was done all the time. But saying that would accomplish nothing.

"stɪl," ləleɪn sɛɾ æbsənli. "pɝhæps aɪ kən bɹɪŋ ə moʊʃən bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl. wi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə pɝsweɪd ði æmɪɝlɪn tə lɪsən tə ə nu kaɪndə pli. wi ʃæl si ɪf aɪ kən fɔɹmjəleɪɾ ə nu ɑɹɡjəmənt."

"Still," Lelaine said absently. "Perhaps I can bring a motion before the Hall. We might be able to persuade the Amyrlin to listen to a new kind of plea. We shall see if I can formulate a new argument."

"wi ʃæl si" əɹ "pɝhæps wi kæn" əɹ "aɪ wɪl kənsɪɾɝ wʌt tə du." nɛvɝ ə fɝm kəmɪtmənt;

"We shall see" or "Perhaps we can" or "I will consider what to do." Never a firm commitment;

ɛvɹi hæf-ɔfɝ keɪm smɪɹd lɪbɝəli wɪð ɡus ɡɹis fəɹ izi ɪskeɪp. laɪt, bʌɾ i wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ wɪɹi ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ænsɝz!

every half-offer came smeared liberally with goose grease for easy escape. Light, but he was growing weary of Aes Sedai answers!

ləleɪn lʊkt ʌp ət hɪm, feɪvɝɪŋ ɪm wɪð ə smaɪl. "naʊ, əz aɪ hæv əɡɹid tə də sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ju, pɝhæps jəl bi wɪlɪŋ tə ɔfɝ mi sʌmθɪŋ. ɡɹeɪt didz ɑɹ ɹɛɹli əkɑmplɪʃt wɪθaʊt ði eɪɾ ə mɛni pɑɹtnɝz, jə meɪ noʊ."

Lelaine looked up at him, favoring him with a smile. "Now, as I have agreed to do something for you, perhaps you will be willing to offer me something. Great deeds are rarely accomplished without the aid of many partners, you may know."

ɡɔɪn saɪd. "spik jəɹ nidz, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Gawyn sighed. "Speak your needs, Aes Sedai."

"jɔɹ sɪstɝ hæz, baɪ ɔl ɹɪpɔɹts, meɪɾ ə vɛɹi ædmɝəbəl ʃoʊɪŋ fəɹ hɝsɛlf ɪn ændɝ," ləleɪn sɛd, əz ɪf ʃi hædn sɛd nɪɹli ði ɪɡzæk seɪm θɪŋ ðə læs θɹi taɪmz ʃid mɛt wɪð ɡɔɪn. "ʃi dɪɾ əv tə stɛp ɑn ə fju toʊz tə sɪkjʊɹ əɹ θɹoʊn, haʊɛvɝ. wʌt dʒju θɪŋk əɹ pɑləsi wɪl bi ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ haʊs tʃɹæmənz fɹuɾ ɔɹtʃɝdz? ʌndɝ jəɹ mʌðɝ, ðə tæks əsɛsməns ɑn ðə lænd wɝ vɛɹi feɪvɝəbəl təwɔɹd tʃɹæmən. wɪl ɪleɪn ɹɪvoʊk ðɪs spɛʃəl pɹɪvlədʒ, əɹ wɪl ʃi tʃɹaɪ tə juz ɪɾ əz hʌni tə suð ðoʊz u stʊɾ əɡɛns hɝ?"

"Your sister has, by all reports, made a very admirable showing for herself in Andor," Lelaine said, as if she hadn't said nearly the exact same thing the last three times she'd met with Gawyn. "She did have to step on a few toes to secure her throne, however. What do you think her policy will be regarding House Traemane's fruit orchards? Under your mother, the tax assessments on the land were very favorable toward Traemane. Will Elayne revoke this special privilege, or will she try to use it as honey to soothe those who stood against her?"

ɡɔɪn staɪfəld ənʌðɝ saɪ. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz keɪm bæk tə ɪleɪn. hi wɑz kənvɪns ðət niðɝ ləleɪn nɔɹ ɹoʊmændə hæɾ ɛni ɹil ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɹɛskjuɪŋ ɛɡwin - ðeɪ wɝ tu plizd wɪð ðɛɹ ɪnkɹis paʊɝ ɪn əɹ æbsəns. noʊ, ðeɪ mɛt wɪð ɡɔɪn kəz ə ðə nu kwin ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn.

Gawyn stifled another sigh. It always came back to Elayne. He was convinced that neither Lelaine nor Romanda had any real interest in rescuing Egwene - they were too pleased with their increased power in her absence. No, they met with Gawyn because of the new queen on the Lion Throne.

hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə waɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ wəd kɛɹ əbaʊɾ æpəl ɔɹtʃɝd tækseɪʃən ɹeɪts.

He had no idea why an Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah would care about apple orchard taxation rates.

ləleɪn wʊdn bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mɑnətɛɹi ɡeɪn; ðət wɑzn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ weɪ. bʌt ʃi wəd wɑn lɛvɝɪdʒ, ə minz ə sɪkjʊɹɪŋ ə feɪvɝəbəl kənɛkʃən wɪð ði ændɔɝən noʊbəl haʊsəz. ɡɔɪn ɹɪzɪstɪɾ ænsɝɪŋ. waɪ hɛlp ðɪs wʊmən? wʌt ɡʊd wɑz ɪt duɪŋ?

Lelaine wouldn't be looking for monetary gain; that wasn't the Aes Sedai way. But she would want leverage, a means of securing a favorable connection with the Andoran noble houses. Gawyn resisted answering. Why help this woman? What good was it doing?

bʌt jɛt . . . kəɾ i bi sɝɾən ʃi wʊdnt wɝk fəɹ ɛɡwinz ɹilis? ɪf i stɑp meɪkɪŋ ðiz miɾɪŋz jusfəl tə ləleɪn, wəd ʃi dɪskəntɪnju ðɛm? wəɾ i faɪn hɪmsɛlf ʃʌɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz wʌn sɔɹs ʌv ɪnfluəns - noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ smɔl - ɪn ðə kæmp?

But yet . . . could he be certain she wouldn't work for Egwene's release? If he stopped making these meetings useful to Lelaine, would she discontinue them? Would he find himself shut out of his one source of influence - no matter how small - in the camp?

"wɛl," hi sɛd, "aɪ θɪŋk ðət maɪ sɪstɝ wɪl bi mɔɹ stʃɹɪk ðən maɪ mʌðɝ wɑz. ʃi ɔlweɪz əz θɔt ðət ðə feɪvɝəbəl pəzɪʃən ə ði ɔɹtʃɝd ɡɹoʊɝz wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dʒʌstəfaɪd."

"Well," he said, "I think that my sister will be more strict than my mother was. She always has thought that the favorable position of the orchard growers was no longer justified."

hi kəd si ðət ləleɪn sʌɾəli bɪɡæn teɪkɪŋ noʊts ɑn wʌɾ i sɛɾ ət ðə bɑɾəm ə hɝ pɑɹtʃmənt. wɑz ðət ðə ɹil ɹizən fəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊt ði ɪŋk ən kwɪl?

He could see that Lelaine subtly began taking notes on what he said at the bottom of her parchment. Was that the real reason for getting out the ink and quill?

hi hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə ænsɝ əz ɑnəsli əz i kʊd, ðoʊ hi hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl nɑt tə lɛt hɪmsɛlf ɡɛt pɹɛs fəɹ tu mʌtʃ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. hɪz kənɛkʃən tə ɪleɪn wɑz ði oʊnli θɪŋ i hæd wɪð wɪtʃ tə bɑɹɡən, ən i hæd tə ɹæʃən ɪz jusfəlnəs tə stʃɹɛtʃ ɪt lɔŋ. ɪɾ ɝk hɪm. ɪleɪn wɑzn ə bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ tʃɪp, ʃi wɑz ɪz sɪstɝ!

He had no choice but to answer as honestly as he could, though he had to be careful not to let himself get pressed for too much information. His connection to Elayne was the only thing he had with which to bargain, and he had to ration his usefulness to stretch it long. It irked him. Elayne wasn't a bargaining chip, she was his sister!

bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl i hæd.

But it was all he had.

"aɪ si," ləleɪn sɛd, "ænd wʌɾ ə ðə nɔɹðɝn tʃɛɹi ɔɹtʃɝdz? ðeɪ hævən bɪn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli pɹədʌktɪv leɪtli, ænd. . . ."

"I see," Lelaine said, "and what of the northern cherry orchards? They haven't been particularly productive lately, and. . . ."

ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, ɡɔɪn lɛf ðə tɛnt. ləleɪn hæd pɹɑɾɪd ɪm əbaʊɾ ændɔɝən tækseɪʃən ɹeɪts fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ən aʊɝ. ænd, wʌns əɡɛn, ɡɔɪn wɑz ənsɝɾən ɪf hiɾ ətʃivd ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl ɪn ɪz vɪzət. hid nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɛɡwin fɹi ət ðɪs ɹeɪt!

Shaking his head, Gawyn left the tent. Lelaine had prodded him about Andoran taxation rates for the better part of an hour. And, once again, Gawyn was uncertain if he'd achieved anything useful in his visit. He'd never get Egwene free at this rate!

əz ɔlweɪz, ə nɑvəs ɪn waɪt weɪɾəd aʊtsaɪd ðə tɛn tə ɛskɔɹɾ ɪm fɹəm ði ɪnɝ kæmp. ðɪs taɪm ðə nɑvəs wɑz ə ʃɔɹt, plʌmp wʊmən u lʊk mɔɹ ðən ə fju jɪɹz tu oʊl tə hæv teɪkən ʌp ðə waɪt.

As always, a novice in white waited outside the tent to escort him from the inner camp. This time the novice was a short, plump woman who looked more than a few years too old to have taken up the white.

ɡɔɪn əlaʊd ðə wʊmən tə liɾ ɪm θɹu ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛn ðət ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ə ɡaɪd, ɹæðɝ ðən ə ɡɑɹd tə si ðəɾ i lɛft əz ɪnstʃɹʌktəd. bɹaɪn wɑz ɹaɪt; ðə wɪmən dɪd nɑt laɪk ənnɛsəsɛɹi bɑɾiz - soʊlʒɝz ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ - wɑndɝɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ nit lɪɾəl ɪməteɪʃən waɪt taʊɝ ʌv ə vɪlədʒ. hi pæs bʌsəlɪŋ ɡɹups ʌv waɪt-klæd wɪmən kɹɔsɪŋ wɔkweɪz, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm wɪð ðə feɪn dɪstʃɹʌs ðə fɹɛnliəst ə pipəl ɔfən ɡeɪv ən aʊtsaɪɾɝ. hi pæst ɛɛs sədaɪ, junəvɝsəli sɛlf-əʃʊɹd wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɔɹ ɹɪtʃ sɪlk əɹ stɪf wʊl. hi pæst səm ɡɹups ʌv wɝkɝ wɪmən, fɑɹ mɔɹ nit ðən ðoʊz aʊɾ ɪn ðə soʊlʒɝ kæmp. ðeɪ wɔkt wɪð ən ɔlmoʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛɹ ðɛmsɛlvz, əz ɪf ðeɪ ɡeɪn ə mɛʒɝ ʌv əθɔɹəɾi baɪ biɪŋ əlaʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹil kæmp.

Gawyn allowed the woman to lead him through the Aes Sedai camp, trying to pretend that she was just a guide, rather than a guard to see that he left as instructed. Bryne was right; the women did not like unnecessary bodies - soldiers in particular - wandering around their neat little imitation White Tower of a village. He passed bustling groups of white-clad women crossing walkways, watching him with the faint distrust the friendliest of people often gave an outsider. He passed Aes Sedai, universally self-assured whether they wore rich silk or stiff wool. He passed some groups of worker women, far more neat than those out in the soldier camp. They walked with an almost Aes Sedai air themselves, as if they gained a measure of authority by being allowed into the real camp.

ɔl ðiz ɡɹups kɹɪskɹɔs θɹu ən oʊpən skwɛɹ ə tʃɹæmpəld widz ðət fɔɹm ðə kɑmən ɛɹiə. ðə moʊs kənfjuzɪŋ θɪŋ i hæd dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ðɪs kæmp hæd tə də wɪð ɛɡwin. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ, hi wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə ɹilaɪz ðət ðə pipəl hɪɹ ɹɪli dɪd si hɝ əz æmɪɝlɪn. ʃi wɑzn sɪmpli ə dəkɔɪ sɛɾ ʌp tə dʒɹɔ aɪɹ, nɔɹ wɑz ʃi ə kælkjəleɪɾəd ɪnsəlt, mɛn tə ɹaɪl ɪleɪɾə. ɛɡwin wɑz æmɪɝlɪn tə ðɛm.

All these groups crisscrossed through an open square of trampled weeds that formed the common area. The most confusing thing he had discovered in this camp had to do with Egwene. More and more, he was coming to realize that the people here really did see her as Amyrlin. She wasn't simply a decoy set up to draw ire, nor was she a calculated insult, meant to rile Elaida. Egwene was Amyrlin to them.

ɑbviəsli, ʃi hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən kəz ðə ɹɛbəlz wɑntəd sʌmwʌn izi tə kəntʃɹoʊl. bʌt ðeɪ dɪdn tʃɹiɾ əɹ əz ə pʌpət - boʊθ ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə spoʊk ə hɝ wɪð ɹɪspɛkt. ðəɹ wɑz ən ædvæntɪdʒ tə ɛɡwinz æbsəns, sɪns ɪt kɹieɪɾəd ə vɔɪɾ ə paʊɝ. ðɛɹfɔɹ, ðeɪ æksɛptɪɾ ɛɡwin əz ə sɔɹs ʌv əθɔɹəɾi. wɑz i ði oʊnli wʌn u ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət ʃid bɪn ən æksɛptɪd dʒʌs mʌnθs əɡoʊ?

Obviously, she had been chosen because the rebels wanted someone easy to control. But they didn't treat her as a puppet - both Lelaine and Romanda spoke of her with respect. There was an advantage to Egwene's absence, since it created a void of power. Therefore, they accepted Egwene as a source of authority. Was he the only one who remembered that she'd been an Accepted just months ago?

ʃi wɑz ɪn oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd. haʊɛvɝ, ʃiɾ ɔlsoʊ ɪmpɹɛs ðə pipəl ɪn ðɪs kæmp. ɪt wɑz laɪk ɪz mʌðɝz oʊn ɹaɪz tə paʊɝ ɪn ændɝ mɛni jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ.

She was in over her head. However, she'd also impressed the people in this camp. It was like his mother's own rise to power in Andor many years before.

bʌt waɪ dɪd ʃi ɹəfjuz tə əlaʊ ə ɹɛskju? tʃɹævlɪŋ hæd bɪn ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd - fɹəm wʌt hid hɝd, ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf hæd ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd ɪt! hi niɾəd tə tɔk tə hɝ. ðən i kəd dʒʌdʒ ɪf əɹ ənwɪlɪŋnɪs tə ɪskeɪp keɪm fɹəm ə fɪɹ ə pʊɾɪŋ ʌðɝz ɪn deɪnʒɝ, əɹ ɪf ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls.

But why did she refuse to allow a rescue? Traveling had been rediscovered - from what he'd heard, Egwene herself had rediscovered it! He needed to talk to her. Then he could judge if her unwillingness to escape came from a fear of putting others in danger, or if it was something else.

hi ənhɑbəl tʃælənʒ fɹəm ðə poʊst ət ðə bɔɹɾɝ bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɑɹmi kæmps, nɑɾəd fɛɹwɛl tə hɪz nɑvəs hænlɝ, ðən swʌŋ ɪndə ðə sæɾəl, tʃɛkɪŋ ðə pəzɪʃən ə ðə sʌn. hi tɝn ɪz maʊn ist əlɔŋ ə pæθweɪ bɪtwin ɑɹmi tɛns, ən sɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə kwɪk tʃɹɑt. hi hædn bɪn laɪɪŋ wən hid toʊld ləleɪn i hæɾ ənʌðɝ əpɔɪnmənt; hid pɹɑməs tə mit bɹaɪn. ʌv kɔɹs, ɡɔɪn hæd sɛɾ ʌp ðə miɾɪŋ kəz hid noʊn i maɪt niɾ ə minz ʌv ɪskeɪpɪŋ ləleɪn. bɹaɪn hæd tɔɾ ɪm ðæt: ɪt dɪdnt ʃoʊ fɪɹ tə pɹipɛɹ jəɹ ɹitʃɹiɾ əhɛɾ ə taɪm. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs pleɪn ɡʊd stʃɹæɾədʒi.

He unhobbled Challenge from the post at the border between Aes Sedai and army camps, nodded farewell to his novice handler, then swung into the saddle, checking the position of the sun. He turned his mount east along a pathway between army tents, and set out in a quick trot. He hadn't been lying when he'd told Lelaine he had another appointment; he'd promised to meet Bryne. Of course, Gawyn had set up the meeting because he'd known he might need a means of escaping Lelaine. Bryne had taught him that: It didn't show fear to prepare your retreat ahead of time. It was just plain good strategy.

wɛl oʊvɝ ən aʊɝz ɹaɪd leɪɾɝ, ɡɔɪn faʊn ɪz oʊl titʃɝ wɛɹ ðeɪd plæn tə mit: wʌn ə ði aʊtlaɪɪŋ ɡɑɹd poʊsts. bɹaɪn wɑz kəndʌktɪŋ ən ɪnspɛkʃən nɑɾ ənlaɪk ðə wʌn ɡɔɪn hæd juz tə mæsk ɪz ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz. ðə dʒɛnɝəl wɑz dʒʌs maʊntɪŋ ɪz bɪɡ-noʊz beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ əz ɡɔɪn tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp, kɹɔsɪŋ ðə skɹʌb ɡɹæs ən wɑn spɹɪŋ widz. ðə ɡɑɹd poʊst sæɾ ɪn ə hɑloʊ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə dʒɛntəl ɪnklaɪn, wɪð ə ɡʊd vju ʌv ði əpɹoʊtʃ fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ. ðə soʊlʒɝz stʊd ɹɪspɛkfəli ɪn ðɛɹ dʒɛnɝəlz pɹɛzəns, ən ðeɪ veɪl ðɛɹ hɑstɪləɾi təwɔɹd ɡɔɪn. ɪt hæd ɡɑɾən ɝaʊn ðət hid lɛd ðə fɔɹs wɪtʃ hæd ɹeɪɾɪd əm soʊ səksɛsfəli. ə stʃɹæɾɪdʒɪst laɪk bɹaɪn kəd ɹɪspɛkt ɡɔɪn fəɹ ɪz skɪl, noʊ mæɾɝ ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɑn ɑpəzət saɪdz, bʌt ðiz mɛn hæd sin kɑliɡz kɪl baɪ ɡɔɪnz tʃɹups.

Well over an hour's ride later, Gawyn found his old teacher where they'd planned to meet: one of the outlying guard posts. Bryne was conducting an inspection not unlike the one Gawyn had used to mask his escape from the Younglings. The general was just mounting his big-nosed bay gelding as Gawyn trotted up, crossing the scrub grass and wan spring weeds. The guard post sat in a hollow on the side of a gentle incline, with a good view of the approach from the north. The soldiers stood respectfully in their general's presence, and they veiled their hostility toward Gawyn. It had gotten around that he'd led the force which had raided them so successfully. A strategist like Bryne could respect Gawyn for his skill, no matter that they had been on opposite sides, but these men had seen colleagues killed by Gawyn's troops.

bɹaɪn tɝn ɪz hɔɹs tə ðə saɪd, nɑɾɪŋ tə ɡɔɪn. "jɔɹ leɪɾɝ ðən jə sɛd jud bi, sʌn."

Bryne turned his horse to the side, nodding to Gawyn. "You're later than you said you'd be, son."

"bʌt nɑt leɪɾɝ ðən jə ɪkspɛktəd?" ɡɔɪn sɛd, pʊlɪŋ tʃælənʒ ʌp.

"But not later than you expected?" Gawyn said, pulling Challenge up.

"nɑɾ əɾ ɔl," ðə stɝɾi mæn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "ju wɝ vɪzəɾɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Not at all," the sturdy man said, smiling. "You were visiting Aes Sedai."

ɡɔɪn ɡɹɪn ət ðæt, ən ðə tu tɝn ðɛɹ maʊns ən bɪɡæn tə kɹɔs ði oʊpən hɪlz təwɔɹd ðə nɔɹθ. bɹaɪn plæn tə ɪnspɛkt ɔl ə ðə ɡɑɹd poʊsts ɑn ðə wɛstɝn saɪɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ə duɾi ðət wəɾ ɪnvɑlv ə lɑɾ ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ, soʊ ɡɔɪn hæɾ ɔfɝd tə əkʌmpəni hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz blɛsɪd lɪɾəl ɛls tə də wɪð ɪz taɪm; fju ʌv ðə soʊlʒɝz wəd spɑɹ wɪð hɪm, ən ðoʊz u wəd tʃɹaɪd dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl tu hɑɹd tə kɑz ən "æksəɾənt." ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ oʊnli sʌfɝ soʊ mʌtʃ ə hɪz pɹɑɾɪŋ, ən ɡɔɪn dɪdn əv ə maɪn fəɹ ðə ɡeɪm ə stoʊnz leɪtli. hi wɑz tu ɑn ɛdʒ, wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɡwin ən fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd əɾ ɪz læk ə pɹəɡɹɛs. ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, hid nɛvɝ bɪn vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət ðə ɡeɪm ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs - nɑt laɪk ɪz mʌðɝ. bɹaɪn hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd ðət ɡɔɪn pɹæktəs ɪɾ ɛniweɪ əz ə mɛθəɾ ə lɝnɪŋ bæɾəlfild stʃɹæɾədʒi.

Gawyn grinned at that, and the two turned their mounts and began to cross the open hills toward the north. Bryne planned to inspect all of the guard posts on the western side of Tar Valon, a duty that would involve a lot of riding, so Gawyn had offered to accompany him. There was blessed little else to do with his time; few of the soldiers would spar with him, and those who would tried just a little too hard to cause an "accident." The Aes Sedai would only suffer so much of his prodding, and Gawyn didn't have a mind for the game of stones lately. He was too on edge, worried about Egwene and frustrated at his lack of progress. The truth was, he'd never been very good at the game in the first place - not like his mother. Bryne had insisted that Gawyn practice it anyway as a method of learning battlefield strategy.

ðə hɪlsaɪdz wɝ skɹæɡli wɪð jɛloʊ widz ən lɑɹksbɹʌʃ, wɪð ɪts taɪni, feɪnli blu livz ən nɑɹl bɹæntʃəz. ðəɹ ʃʊɾə bɪn waɪldflaʊɹz koʊɾɪŋ ðə hɪlz ɪn pætʃəz, bʌt nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl wʌn blumd. ðə lændskeɪp fɛl sɪkli - jɛloʊ ɪn pætʃəz, waɪɾɪʃ blu ɪn ʌðɝz, wɪð dʒɛnɝəs hɛlpɪŋz ə dɛd bɹaʊn skɹʌb ðət hædn ɹiɡɹoʊn æftɝ ðə hɑɹʃ wɪntɝ.

The hillsides were scraggly with yellow weeds and larksbrush, with its tiny, faintly blue leaves and gnarled branches. There should have been wildflowers coating the hills in patches, but not a single one bloomed. The landscape felt sickly - yellow in patches, whitish blue in others, with generous helpings of dead brown scrub that hadn't regrown after the harsh winter.

"æn ɑɹ jə gɑnə tɛl mi haʊ ðə miɾɪŋ wɛnt?" bɹaɪn æskt əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd, ə skwɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝz fɑloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪn əz ən ɑnɝ ɡɑɹd.

"And are you going to tell me how the meeting went?" Bryne asked as they rode, a squad of soldiers following behind as an honor guard.

"aɪl bɛt juv ɡɛs ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi əz wɛl."

"I'll bet you have guessed that already as well."

"oʊ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz ən ənjuʒəwəl taɪm, ən stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪvɛns ɑɹ kɑmən. pɝhæps ləleɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə fɔɹɡoʊ skimɪŋ fəɹ ə taɪm ən æktʃəli  lɪsən tə jəɹ pliz."

"Oh, I don't know," Bryne said. "It is an unusual time, and strange events are common. Perhaps Lelaine decided to forgo scheming for a time and actually listen to your pleas."

ɡɔɪn ɡɹɪməst. "aɪ θɪŋk jud sunɝ faɪn ə tʃɹɑlɑk u hæz teɪkən ʌp wivɪŋ ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæz ɡɪvən ʌp skimɪŋ."

Gawyn grimaced. "I think you'd sooner find a Trolloc who has taken up weaving than an Aes Sedai who has given up scheming."

"aɪ də bɪliv ðət jə wɝ wɔɹnd," bɹaɪn sɛd.

"I do believe that you were warned," Bryne said.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɑɹɡjəmən ðət ɡɔɪn kəd meɪk, soʊ ðeɪ sɪmpli ɹoʊɾ ɪn saɪləns fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm, pæsɪŋ ðə dɪstən ɹɪvɝ tə ðə ɹaɪt. bɪɑn ðæt, ðə taʊɝ ən ɹufs ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ə pɹɪzən.

There was no argument that Gawyn could make, so they simply rode in silence for a short time, passing the distant river to the right. Beyond that, the tower and roofs of Tar Valon. A prison.

"wil ɪvɛntʃəwəli nid tə dɪskʌs ðət ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz jə lɛf bɪhaɪnd, ɡɔɪn," bɹaɪn sɛd sʌɾənli, aɪz fɔɹwɝd.

"We'll eventually need to discuss that group of soldiers you left behind, Gawyn," Bryne said suddenly, eyes forward.

"aɪ doʊn si wʌt ðəɹ ɪz tə dɪskʌs," ɡɔɪn sɛd, wɪtʃ wɑzn kəmplitli tʃɹuθfəl. hi hæd səspɪʃənz ʌv wʌt bɹaɪn wəɾ æsk, ən i dɪdn lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən.

"I don't see what there is to discuss," Gawyn said, which wasn't completely truthful. He had suspicions of what Bryne would ask, and he didn't look forward to the conversation.

bɹaɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪl niɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, læd. loʊkeɪʃənz, tʃɹup kaʊns, ɪkwɪpmən lɪsts. aɪ noʊ jə wɝ steɪdʒɪŋ fɹəm wʌn ə ðə vɪlədʒəz tə ði ist, bʌt wɪtʃ wʌn? haʊ mɛni ɑɹ ɪn jəɹ fɔɹs, ən wʌt kaɪndə səpɔɹɾ ɑɹ ɪleɪɾəz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡɪvɪŋ ðɛm?"

Bryne shook his head. "I'll need information, lad. Locations, troop counts, equipment lists. I know you were staging from one of the villages to the east, but which one? How many are in your force, and what kind of support are Elaida's Aes Sedai giving them?"

ɡɔɪn kɛpt ɪz aɪz fɔɹwɝd. "aɪ keɪm tə hɛlp ɛɡwin. nɑt tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ðoʊz u tʃɹʌstɪd mi."

Gawyn kept his eyes forward. "I came to help Egwene. Not to betray those who trusted me."

"ju ɔlɹɛɾi bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm."

"You already betrayed them."

"noʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ əbændən ðɛm, bʌɾ aɪ hæv nɑt bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm. ən aɪ də nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə."

"No," Gawyn said firmly. "I abandoned them, but I have not betrayed them. And I do not intend to."

"æn jə ɪkspɛk mi tə lɛɾ ə pətɛnʃəl ædvæntɪdʒ daɪ ənteɪkən?" bɹaɪn æskt, tɝnɪŋ tə hɪm. "wʌt juv ɪn ðət bɹeɪn ə jʊɹz kəd seɪv laɪvz."

"And you expect me to let a potential advantage die untaken?" Bryne asked, turning to him. "What you have in that brain of yours could save lives."

"ɔɹ kɑs lɪvz," ɡɔɪn sɛd, "ɪf jə lʊk əɾ ɪt fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪd."

"Or cost lives," Gawyn said, "if you look at it from the other side."

"doʊn meɪk ðɪs dɪfəkəlt, ɡɔɪn."

"Don't make this difficult, Gawyn."

"ɔɹ wʌt?" ɡɔɪn æskt. "jul pʊt mi tə ðə kwɛstʃən?"

"Or what?" Gawyn asked. "You'll put me to the question?"

"jud sʌfɝ fəɹ ðɛm?"

"You'd suffer for them?"

"ðeɪ ɑɹ maɪ mɛn," ɡɔɪn sɛd sɪmpli. ɔɹ, ət list, ðeɪ wɝ. iðɝ weɪ, hi hæd hæɾ ɪnʌf ə biɪŋ pʊʃt ɝaʊn baɪ sɝkəmstænsəz ən wɔɹz. hi wəd ɡɪv noʊ lɔɪəlti tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt niðɝ wəɾ i ɔfɝ ɪt tə ðiz ɹɛbəlz. ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn hɛld ɪz hɑɹɾ ən ɪz ɑnɝ. ən ɪf i kʊdnt ɡɪv ɪt tə ðɛm, hi wəd ɡɪv ɪt tə ændɝ - ən ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld - baɪ hʌntɪŋ daʊn ɹænd ælθɹ ən siɪŋ ɪm dɛd.

"They are my men," Gawyn said simply. Or, at least, they were. Either way, he had had enough of being pushed around by circumstances and wars. He would give no loyalty to the White Tower, but neither would he offer it to these rebels. Egwene and Elayne held his heart and his honor. And if he couldn't give it to them, he would give it to Andor - and the entire world - by hunting down Rand al'Thor and seeing him dead.

ɹænd ælθɹ. ɡɔɪn dɪdn bɪliv bɹaɪnz dɪfɛns ə ðə mæn. oʊ, hi bɪliv ðət bɹaɪn mɛnt wʌɾ i sɛd - bʌɾ i wɑz mɪsteɪkən. ɪt kəd hæpən tə ðə bɛst ə pipəl, teɪkən ɪn baɪ ðə kɝɪzmə ʌv ə kɹitʃɝ laɪk ælθɹ. hi hæd fuld ɪleɪn hɝsɛlf. ði oʊnli weɪ tə hɛlp ɛni ʌv əm wəd bi tə ɪkspoʊz ðɪs dʒɹæɡən ən dɪspoʊz ə hɪm.

Rand al'Thor. Gawyn didn't believe Bryne's defense of the man. Oh, he believed that Bryne meant what he said - but he was mistaken. It could happen to the best of people, taken in by the charisma of a creature like al'Thor. He had fooled Elayne herself. The only way to help any of them would be to expose this Dragon and dispose of him.

hi lʊkt oʊvɝ ət bɹaɪn, hu tɝn əweɪ. hi wɑz stɪl θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz, laɪkli. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðət bɹaɪn wəd pʊt ɡɔɪn tə ðə kwɛstʃən. ɡɔɪn nu ðə dʒɛnɝəl, ən ɪz sɛns ʌv ɑnɝ, tu wɛl. ɪt wʊdn hæpən. bʌt bɹaɪn maɪt dɪsaɪd tə ɪmpɹɪzən ɡɔɪn. pɝhæps ɪt wəd bi waɪz tə ɔfɝ ɪm sʌmθɪŋ.

He looked over at Bryne, who turned away. He was still thinking about the Younglings, likely. It was unlikely that Bryne would put Gawyn to the question. Gawyn knew the general, and his sense of honor, too well. It wouldn't happen. But Bryne might decide to imprison Gawyn. Perhaps it would be wise to offer him something.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ juðz, bɹaɪn," ɡɔɪn sɛd.

"They are youths, Bryne," Gawyn said.

bɹaɪn fɹaʊnd.

Bryne frowned.

"juðz," ɡɔɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd. "bɛɹli pæs ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ ɑn ðə spɑɹɪŋ fild, nɑɾ ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild. ðɛɹ hɑɹts ɑɹ ɡʊd, ən ðɛɹ skɪlz saʊnd, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ mʌtʃ lɛs ə θɹɛt tə jə naʊ ðəɾ aɪm ɡɔn. aɪ wɑz ðə wʌn u nu jəɹ stʃɹæɾədʒi. wɪθaʊt mi, ðəl əv ə mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ taɪm ə ðɛɹ ɹeɪdz. aɪ səspɛk ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ kəntɪnju tə stʃɹaɪk, ðeɪ ʃæl əv ðɛɹ deɪ wɪð ðə bʊtʃɝ sun ɪnʌf. noʊ nid fəɹ mi tə heɪsən əm əlɔŋ."

"Youths," Gawyn repeated. "Barely past their training. They belong on the sparring field, not on the battlefield. Their hearts are good, and their skills sound, but they are much less a threat to you now that I am gone. I was the one who knew your strategy. Without me, they will have a much harder time of their raids. I suspect that if they continue to strike, they shall have their day with the butcher soon enough. No need for me to hasten them along."

"vɛɹi wɛl," bɹaɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ wɪl weɪt. bʌɾ ɪf ðɛɹ ɹeɪdz kəntɪnju tə bi ɪfɛktɪv, jəl hɪɹ ðɪs kwɛstʃən fɹəm mi əɡɛn."

"Very well," Bryne replied. "I will wait. But if their raids continue to be effective, you will hear this question from me again."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd. ðə bɛs θɪŋ i kəd də fəɹ ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz wəd bi tə hɛlp ɛn ðɪs dɪvɪʒən bɪtwin ðə ɹɛbəlz ən ðə lɔɪəlɪsts. bʌt ðət sim fɑɹ bɪɑn ðə skoʊp ʌv wʌɾ i kəɾ əkɑmplɪʃ. pɝhæps æftɝ i fɹiɾ ɛɡwin i kəd θɪŋk ə səm weɪ tə hɛlp. laɪt! ðeɪ kʊdn ɹɪli bi ɪntɛndɪŋ tə ɡoʊ tə bloʊz, kəd ðeɪ? ðə skɝmɪʃ fɑloʊɪŋ sɪuən sɑntʃəz fɔl hæd bɪn bæɾ ɪnʌf. wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf ɑɹmiz mɛt hɪɹ, dʒʌst aʊtsaɪɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn? ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɔɹɾɝ faɪɾɪŋ wɔɹɾɝ ɑn ə bæɾəlfild? ə dɪzæstɝ.

Gawyn nodded. The best thing he could do for the Younglings would be to help end this division between the rebels and the loyalists. But that seemed far beyond the scope of what he could accomplish. Perhaps after he freed Egwene he could think of some way to help. Light! They couldn't really be intending to go to blows, could they? The skirmish following Siuan Sanche's fall had been bad enough. What would happen if armies met here, just outside of Tar Valon? Aes Sedai against Aes Sedai, Warder fighting Warder on a battlefield? A disaster.

"ɪt kæn kʌm tə ðæt," hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf seɪɪŋ.

"It can't come to that," he found himself saying.

bɹaɪn lʊkt ət ɡɔɪn əz ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz kəntɪnjuɾ əkɹɔs ðə fild.

Bryne looked at Gawyn as their horses continued across the field.

"ju kæn ətæk, bɹaɪn," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ə sidʒ ɪz wʌn θɪŋ. bʌt wʌt wɪl jə də ɪf ðeɪ ɔɹɾɝ jə tə maʊn ən əsɔlt?"

"You can't attack, Bryne," Gawyn said. "A siege is one thing. But what will you do if they order you to mount an assault?"

"wʌɾ aɪ ɔlweɪz du," bɹaɪn sɛd. "oʊbeɪ."

"What I always do," Bryne said. "Obey."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"aɪ ɡeɪv maɪ wɝd, ɡɔɪn."

"I gave my word, Gawyn."

"æn haʊ mɛni dɛθs ɪz ðət wɝd wɝθ? əsɔltɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ wəd bi ə dɪzæstɝ. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ slaɪɾɪd ðiz ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ fil, ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ ɹɛkənsɪlieɪʃən ɪf ɪt hæpənz baɪ ðə sɔɹd."

"And how many deaths is that word worth? Assaulting the White Tower would be a disaster. No matter how slighted these rebel Aes Sedai may feel, there will be no reconciliation if it happens by the sword."

"ðæts nɑɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒən," bɹaɪn sɛd. hi ɡlænst ət ɡɔɪn, ə θɔtfəl ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs.

"That's not our decision," Bryne said. He glanced at Gawyn, a thoughtful expression on his face.

"wʌt?" ɡɔɪn æskt.

"What?" Gawyn asked.

"aɪm wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ ɪt mæɾɝz tə ju. aɪ θɔt jə wɝ dʒʌs hɪɹ fəɹ ɛɡwin."

"I'm wondering why it matters to you. I thought you were just here for Egwene."

"aɪ. . . ." ɡɔɪn flaʊndɝd.

"I. . . ." Gawyn floundered.

"hu ɑɹ ju, ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd?" bɹaɪn æskt, pɹɑɾɪŋ fɝðɝ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jəɹ ælidʒiænsɪz, ɹɪli?"

"Who are you, Gawyn Trakand?" Bryne asked, prodding further. "What are your allegiances, really?"

"ju noʊ mi bɛɾɝ ðən moʊst, ɡɛɹɪθ."

"You know me better than most, Gareth."

"aɪ noʊ hu jə wɝ səpoʊz tə bi," bɹaɪn sɛd. "fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd, tʃɹeɪn baɪ wɔɹɾɝz bʌt bɑndəd tə noʊ wʊmən."

"I know who you were supposed to be," Bryne said. "First Prince of the Sword, trained by Warders but bonded to no woman."

"æn ðæts nɑt wʌɾ aɪ æm?" ɡɔɪn æsk tɛstəli.

"And that's not what I am?" Gawyn asked testily.

"pis, sʌn," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ðɪs wɑzn mɛn tə bi ən ɪnsəlt. dʒʌst ən ɑbzɝveɪʃən. aɪ noʊ jə wɝ nɛvɝ əz sɪŋɡəl-maɪndəɾ əz jəɹ bɹʌðɝ. aɪ səpoʊz aɪ ʃʊɾə sin ðɪs ɪn ju."

"Peace, son," Bryne said. "This wasn't meant to be an insult. Just an observation. I know you were never as single-minded as your brother. I suppose I should have seen this in you."

ɡɔɪn tɝn təwɔɹd ði eɪdʒɪŋ dʒɛnɝəl. wʌt wɑz ðə mæn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?

Gawyn turned toward the aging general. What was the man talking about?

bɹaɪn saɪd. "ɪts ə θɪŋ moʊst soʊlʒɝz nɛvɝ feɪs, ɡɔɪn. oʊ, ðeɪ meɪ kənsɪɾɝ ɪt, bʌt ðeɪ doʊn lɛɾ ɪt tɔɹmɛn ðɛm. ðɪs kwɛstʃən ɪz fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls, sʌmwʌn haɪɝ ʌp."

Bryne sighed. "It's a thing most soldiers never face, Gawyn. Oh, they may consider it, but they don't let it torment them. This question is for someone else, someone higher up."

"wʌt kwɛstʃən?" ɡɔɪn æskt, pɝplɛkst.

"What question?" Gawyn asked, perplexed.

"tʃuzɪŋ ə saɪd," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ænd, wʌns juv pɪkt wʌn, dəsaɪɾɪŋ ɪf jə meɪd ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən. ðə fʊt soʊlʒɝz doʊn əv tə meɪk ðɪs tʃɔɪs, bʌt ðoʊz ʌv əs u lɛd . . . jɛs, aɪ kən si ɪɾ ɪn ju. ðət skɪl ə jʊɹz wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ɪz noʊ smɔl ɡɪft. wɛɹ dʒju juz ɪt?"

"Choosing a side," Bryne said. "And, once you've picked one, deciding if you made the right decision. The foot soldiers don't have to make this choice, but those of us who lead . . . yes, I can see it in you. That skill of yours with the sword is no small gift. Where do you use it?"

"fɔɹ ɪleɪn," ɡɔɪn sɛd kwɪkli.

"For Elayne," Gawyn said quickly.

"æz jə də naʊ?" bɹaɪn æskt wɪð əmjuzmənt.

"As you do now?" Bryne asked with amusement.

"wɛl, wʌns aɪ seɪv ɛɡwin."

"Well, once I save Egwene."

"æn ɪf ɛɡwin woʊnt ɡoʊ?" bɹaɪn æskt. "aɪ noʊ ðət lʊk ɪn jəɹ aɪz, læd. aɪ ɔlsoʊ noʊ səm smɔl bɪɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ. ʃi woʊn liv ðɪs bæɾəlfild əntɪl ə vɪktɝ əz bɪn tʃoʊzən."

"And if Egwene won't go?" Bryne asked. "I know that look in your eyes, lad. I also know some small bit about Egwene al'Vere. She won't leave this battlefield until a victor has been chosen."

"aɪl teɪk əɹ əweɪ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "bæk tə ændɝ."

"I'll take her away," Gawyn said. "Back to Andor."

"ænd wɪl jə fɔɹs əɹ tə ɡoʊ?" bɹaɪn æskt. "æz jə fɔɹs jəɹ weɪ ɪndə maɪ kæmp? wɪl jə bɪkʌm ə bʊli ən ə fʊtpæd, ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl oʊnli kəz ə jəɹ əbɪləɾi tə kɪl əɹ pʌnɪʃ ðoʊz u dɪsəɡɹi wɪð ju?"

"And will you force her to go?" Bryne asked. "As you forced your way into my camp? Will you become a bully and a footpad, remarkable only because of your ability to kill or punish those who disagree with you?"

ɡɔɪn dɪdn ænsɝ.

Gawyn didn't answer.

"hum tə sɝv?" bɹaɪn sɛd, θɔtfəl. "aʊɝ oʊn skɪl fɹaɪɾənz ʌs, səmtaɪmz. wʌɾ ɪz ði əbɪləɾi tə kɪl ɪf wʌn əz noʊ aʊtlɛt fəɹ ɪt? ə weɪstəd tælənt? ðə pæθweɪ tə bɪkʌmɪŋ ə mɝɾɝɝ? ðə paʊɝ tə pɹətɛkt ən pɹəzɝv ɪz dɔntɪŋ. soʊ jə lʊk fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə ɡɪv ðə skɪl tə, sʌmwʌn u wɪl juz ɪt waɪzli. ðə nid tə meɪk ə dɪsɪʒən tʃuz ət ju, ivən æftɝ juv meɪɾ ɪt. aɪ si ðə kwɛstʃən mɔɹ ɪn jʌŋɡɝ mɛn. wi oʊl haʊnz, wɝ dʒʌs hæpi tə hæv ə pleɪs baɪ ðə hɑɹθ. ɪf sʌmwʌn tɛlz əs tə faɪt, wi doʊnt wɑnə ʃeɪk θɪŋz ʌp tu mʌtʃ. bʌt ðə jʌŋ mɛn . . . ðeɪ wʌndɝ."

"Whom to serve?" Bryne said, thoughtful. "Our own skill frightens us, sometimes. What is the ability to kill if one has no outlet for it? A wasted talent? The pathway to becoming a murderer? The power to protect and preserve is daunting. So you look for someone to give the skill to, someone who will use it wisely. The need to make a decision chews at you, even after you've made it. I see the question more in younger men. We old hounds, we're just happy to have a place by the hearth. If someone tells us to fight, we don't want to shake things up too much. But the young men . . . they wonder."

"dɪd jə kwɛstʃən, wʌns?" ɡɔɪn æskt.

"Did you question, once?" Gawyn asked.

"jɛs," bɹaɪn sɛd. "mɔɹ ðən wʌns. aɪ wɑzn kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz ə ɹæŋk-kæptən. aɪ wʌndɝd ðɛn, mɛni taɪmz."

"Yes," Bryne said. "More than once. I wasn't Captain-General during the Aiel War, but I was a rank-captain. I wondered then, many times."

"haʊ kəd jə kwɛstʃən jəɹ saɪd dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz?" ɡɔɪn sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"How could you question your side during the Aiel war, of all things?" Gawyn said, frowning.

"ðeɪ keɪm tə slɔɾɝ."

"They came to slaughter."

"ðeɪ dɪdn kʌm fəɹ ʌs," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd ðə kɛɹhinɪn. ʌv kɔɹs, ðət wɑzn soʊ izi tə si ət fɝst, bʌt tʃɹuθ bi toʊld, səm ʌv əs wʌndɝd. leɪmən dɪzɝvd ɪz dɛθ. waɪ ʃəd wi daɪ tə stæn ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ɪt? meɪbi mɔɹ ʌv əs ʃʊɾə æsk ðə kwɛstʃən."

"They didn't come for us," Bryne said. "They just wanted the Cairhienin. Of course, that wasn't so easy to see at first, but truth be told, some of us wondered. Laman deserved his death. Why should we die to stand in the way of it? Maybe more of us should have asked the question."

"ðɛn wʌts ði ænsɝ?" ɡɔɪn æskt. "wɛɹ dʒju pʊt jəɹ tʃɹʌst? hum də aɪ sɝv?"

"Then what's the answer?" Gawyn asked. "Where do you put your trust? Whom do I serve?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," bɹaɪn sɛd fɹæŋkli.

"I don't know," Bryne said frankly.

"ðɛn waɪ æsk ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs?" ɡɔɪn snæpt, pʊlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ʌp ʃɔɹt.

"Then why ask in the first place?" Gawyn snapped, pulling his horse up short.

bɹaɪn ɹeɪn ɪn ɪz ænəməl, tɝnɪŋ bæk. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ði ænsɝ kəz ðəɹ ɪzənt wʌn. ət list, itʃ pɝsənz ænsɝ ɪz ðɛɹ oʊn. wən aɪ wɑz jʌŋ, aɪ fɔt fəɹ ɑnɝ. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, aɪ ɹilaɪz ðət ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl ɑnɝ tə bi faʊn ɪn kɪlɪŋ, ən aɪ faʊn ðəɾ aɪ hæd tʃeɪnʒd. ðən aɪ fɔt kəz aɪ sɝv jəɹ mʌðɝ. aɪ tʃɹʌstɪd hɝ. wən ʃi feɪl mi, aɪ bɪɡæn tə wʌndɝ əɡɛn. wʌɾ ʌv ɔl ðoʊz jɪɹz ə sɝvəs? wʌɾ ə ðə mɛn aɪd kɪld ɪn əɹ neɪm? wʌɾ ɛni ʌv ðət min?"

Bryne reined in his animal, turning back. "I don't know the answer because there isn't one. At least, each person's answer is their own. When I was young, I fought for honor. Eventually, I realized that there was little honor to be found in killing, and I found that I had changed. Then I fought because I served your mother. I trusted her. When she failed me, I began to wonder again. What of all those years of service? What of the men I'd killed in her name? What did any of that mean?"

hi tɝn ən flɪkt ɪz ɹeɪnz, muvɪŋ əɡɛn. ɡɔɪn heɪstəd tʃælənʒ tə kætʃ ʌp.

He turned and flicked his reins, moving again. Gawyn hasted Challenge to catch up.

"ju wʌndɝ waɪ aɪm hɪɹ, ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɪn ændɝ?" bɹaɪn æskt. "ɪts kəz aɪ kæn lɛt ɡoʊ. ɪts kəz ðə wɝld ɪz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, ən aɪ nid tə bi pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. ɪts kəz wʌns ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ændɝ wɑz teɪkən fɹəm mi, aɪ niɾəd ə nu pleɪs fəɹ maɪ lɔɪəlti. ðə pæɾɝn bɹɔt mi ðɪs ɑpɝtunəɾi."

"You wonder why I'm here, instead of in Andor?" Bryne asked. "It's because I can't let go. It's because the world is changing, and I need to be part of it. It's because once everything in Andor was taken from me, I needed a new place for my loyalty. The Pattern brought me this opportunity."

"æn jə tʃoʊz ɪt dʒʌs kəz ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ?"

"And you chose it just because it was there?"

"noʊ," bɹaɪn sɛd. "aɪ pɪkt ɪt kəz ɪm ə ful." hi mɛt ɡɔɪnz aɪz. "bʌɾ aɪ steɪd kəz ɪt wɑz ɹaɪt. ðət wɪtʃ əz bɪn bɹoʊkən mʌs bi meɪd hoʊl, ən aɪv sin wʌɾ ə tɛɹəbəl liɾɝ kən də tə ə kɪŋdəm. ɪleɪɾə kæn bi əlaʊd tə pʊl ðɪs wɝl daʊn wɪð hɝ."

"No," Bryne said. "I picked it because I'm a fool." He met Gawyn's eyes. "But I stayed because it was right. That which has been broken must be made whole, and I've seen what a terrible leader can do to a kingdom. Elaida can't be allowed to pull this world down with her."

ɡɔɪn stɑɹɾəd.

Gawyn started.

"jɛs," bɹaɪn sɛd. "aɪv æktʃəli  kʌm tə bɪliv ðɛm. ful wɪmən. bʌt baɪ ðə laɪt, ɡɔɪn, ðəɹ ɹaɪt. wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ ɪz ɹaɪt. ʃiz ɹaɪt."

"Yes," Bryne said. "I've actually come to believe them. Fool women. But by the Light, Gawyn, they're right. What I'm doing is right. She's right."

"hu?"

"Who?"

bɹaɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, mʌɾɝɪŋ. "blʌɾi wʊmən."

Bryne shook his head, muttering. "Bloody woman."

ɛɡwin? ɡɔɪn wʌndɝd.

Egwene? Gawyn wondered.

"maɪ moʊɾɪvz ɑɹən ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ju, sʌn," bɹaɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ nɑt wʌn ə maɪ soʊlʒɝz. bʌt jə nid tə meɪk səm dɪsɪʒənz. ɪn ðə deɪz kʌmɪŋ, jəl nid tə hæv ə saɪɾ ən jəl nid tə noʊ waɪ juv tʃoʊzən ɪt. ðæts ɔl əl seɪ ɑn ðə mæɾɝ."

"My motives aren't important to you, son," Bryne said. "You're not one of my soldiers. But you need to make some decisions. In the days coming, you'll need to have a side and you'll need to know why you've chosen it. That's all I'll say on the matter."

hi kɪkt ɪz hɔɹs ɪndə ə fæstɝ ɡeɪt. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ɡɔɪn kəd pɪk aʊɾ ənʌðɝ ɡɑɹd poʊst.

He kicked his horse into a faster gait. In the distance, Gawyn could pick out another guard post.

hi hʌŋ bæk əz bɹaɪn ən ɪz soʊlʒɝz əpɹoʊtʃt ɪt.

He hung back as Bryne and his soldiers approached it.

pɪk ə saɪd. wʌɾ ɪf ɛɡwin wʊdnt ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm?

Pick a side. What if Egwene wouldn't go with him?

bɹaɪn wɑz ɹaɪt. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz kʌmɪŋ. jə kəd smɛl ɪɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ, fil ɪɾ ɪn ðə wik sʌnlaɪt ðət mænədʒ tə ʃoʊldɝ ɪts weɪ θɹu ðə klaʊdz. jə kəd sɛns ɪt, dɪstənli, ɪn ðə nɔɹθ, kɹæklɪŋ laɪk ənsin ɛnɝdʒi ɑn ðət dɑɹk hɝaɪzən.

Bryne was right. Something was coming. You could smell it in the air, feel it in the weak sunlight that managed to shoulder its way through the clouds. You could sense it, distantly, in the north, crackling like unseen energy on that dark horizon.

wɔɹ, bæɾəlz, kɑnflɪks, tʃeɪnʒəz. ɡɔɪn fɛlt əz ɪf i dɪdnt noʊ wʌt ðə dɪfɹən saɪdz wɝ.

War, battles, conflicts, changes. Gawyn felt as if he didn't know what the different sides were.

lɛɾ əloʊn wɪtʃ wʌn tə pɪk fəɹ hɪmsɛlf.

Let alone which one to pick for himself.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾiwʌn

CHAPTER 31

eɪ pɹɑməs tə luz θɝɪn kædzueɪn kɛpt əɹ kloʊk ɑn, hʊɾ ʌp, dɪspaɪt ðə mʌɡənəs ðət stʃɹeɪn əɹ əbɪləɾi tə "ɪɡnɔɹ"

A Promise to Lews Therin Cadsuane kept her cloak on, hood up, despite the mugginess that strained her ability to "ignore"

ðə hit. ʃi dɛɹd nɑt loʊɝ ðə hʊɾ əɹ ɹimuv ðə kloʊk. ælθɹz wɝdz hæd bɪn spəsɪfɪk; ɪf i sɔ hɝ feɪs, ʃi wəd bi ɛksəkjuɾəd. ʃi wʊdn ɹɪsk əɹ laɪf tə pɹɪvɛn ə fju aʊɝz ə dɪskʌmfɝt, ivən ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ælθɹ wɑz seɪfli bæk ɪn ɪz nuli əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪd mænʃən. ðə bɔɪ ɔfən əpɪɹd wɛɹ i wɑzn ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ wɑntəd.

the heat. She dared not lower the hood or remove the cloak. Al'Thor's words had been specific; if he saw her face, she would be executed. She wouldn't risk her life to prevent a few hours of discomfort, even if she thought al'Thor was safely back in his newly appropriated mansion. The boy often appeared where he wasn't expected or wanted.

ʃi wɑzn əbaʊt tə lɛɾ ɪm ɛɡzaɪl hɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə mɔɹ paʊɝ ə mæn hɛld, ðə mɔɹ laɪkli hi wɑz tə bi ən ɪɾiət wɪð ɪt. ɡɪv ə mæn wʌn kaʊ, ən hid kɛɹ fəɹ ɪt wɪð kənsɝn, juzɪŋ ɪts mɪlk tə fiɾ ɪz fæmli. ɡɪv ə mæn tɛn kaʊz, ən i wɑz laɪkli tə θɪŋk hɪmsɛlf ɹɪtʃ - ðən lɛɾ ɔl tɛn stɑɹv fəɹ læk ʌv ətɛnʃən.

She wasn't about to let him exile her, of course. The more power a man held, the more likely he was to be an idiot with it. Give a man one cow, and he'd care for it with concern, using its milk to feed his family. Give a man ten cows, and he was likely to think himself rich - then let all ten starve for lack of attention.

ʃi klɑmp daʊn ðə bɔɹdwɔk, pæsɪŋ bænɝd bɪldɪŋz laɪk bɑksəz stækt ətɑp wʌn ənʌðɝ. ʃi wɑzn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli pliz tə bi ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən əɡɛn. ʃi hæd nʌθɪŋ əɡɛns ðə dəmɑni; ʃi dʒʌs pɹəfɝd sɪɾiz ðət wɝn soʊ kɹaʊɾəd. ən wɪð ðə pɹɑbləmz ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd, ðə pleɪs wɑz mɔɹ pæk ðən nɔɹməl. ɹɛfjudʒiz kəntɪnjud tə tʃɹɪkəl ɪn dɪspaɪt ðə ɹumɝz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ælθɹz ɝaɪvəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ʃi pæst ə klʌstɝ ə ðɛm ɪn ði æli tə hɝ lɛft, ə fæmli, feɪsəz dɑɹkən baɪ dɝt.

She clomped down the boardwalk, passing bannered buildings like boxes stacked atop one another. She wasn't particularly pleased to be in Bandar Eban again. She had nothing against the Domani; she just preferred cities that weren't so crowded. And with the problems in the countryside, the place was more packed than normal. Refugees continued to trickle in despite the rumors regarding al'Thor's arrival in the city. She passed a cluster of them in the alley to her left, a family, faces darkened by dirt.

ælθɹ pɹɑməs fud. ðət bɹɔt hʌŋɡɹi maʊðz, nʌn iɡɝ tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ fɑɹmz, ivən æftɝ ðeɪ wɝ ɡɪvən fud. ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd wɑz stɪl tu keɪɑɾɪk, ən ðə fud hɪɹ tu nu. ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz kʊdn bi sɝɾən ðə ɡɹeɪn wʊdn dʒʌst spɔɪl, əz soʊ mʌtʃ dɪd ɹisənli. noʊ, ðeɪ steɪd, pækɪŋ ðə sɪɾi, kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɪt.

Al'Thor promised food. That brought hungry mouths, none eager to return to their farms, even after they were given food. The countryside was still too chaotic, and the food here too new. The refugees couldn't be certain the grain wouldn't just spoil, as so much did recently. No, they stayed, packing the city, crowding it.
