kædzueɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, kəntɪnjuɪŋ daʊn ðə bɔɹdwɔk, ðoʊz ɹɛtʃɪd klɑɡz klæɾɝɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wʊd. ðə sɪɾi wɑz feɪməs fəɹ ðiz lɔŋ, stɝɾi wɔkweɪz, wɪtʃ əlaʊd fʊt tʃɹæfɪk tə əvɔɪd ðə mʌɾ ə ðə stʃɹits. kɑbəlz wʊɾə fɪks ðæt, bʌt ðə dəmɑni ɔfən pɹaɪɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ɑn biɪŋ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ə ðə wɝld. ɪndɪdʒɛstəbli spaɪsi fud wɪð dʒɹɛdfəl iɾɪŋ jutɛnsəlz. ə kæpəɾəl fɪld wɪð fɹɪvələs bænɝz, sɛɾ ɑn ə hjudʒ pɔɹt. skændələs dʒɹɛsəz ɑn ðə wɪmən; lɔŋ, θɪn mʌstæʃɪz ɑn ðə mɛn ən ən ɔlmoʊst si foʊklaɪk fɑndnəs fəɹ ɪɹɪŋz.

Cadsuane shook her head, continuing down the boardwalk, those wretched clogs clattering against the wood. The city was famous for these long, sturdy walkways, which allowed foot traffic to avoid the mud of the streets. Cobbles would have fixed that, but the Domani often prided themselves on being different from the rest of the world. Indigestibly spicy food with dreadful eating utensils. A capital filled with frivolous banners, set on a huge port. Scandalous dresses on the women; long, thin mustaches on the men and an almost Sea Folklike fondness for earrings.

hʌnʒɹədz ə ðoʊz bænɝz flæpt ɪn ðə wɪn əz kædzueɪn pæst, ən ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ əɡɛns ðə tɛmteɪʃən tə pʊl ɔf əɹ hʊɾ ən fil ðə wɪn ɑn əɹ feɪs. laɪt-kɝst oʊʃən ɛɹ.

Hundreds of those banners flapped in the wind as Cadsuane passed, and she gritted her teeth against the temptation to pull off her hood and feel the wind on her face. Light-cursed ocean air.

nɔɹməli, bændɑɹ ɛbən wɑz tʃɪli ən ɹeɪni. ɹɛɹli hæd ʃi fɛlt ɪt ðɪs wɔɹm. ðə hjumɪɾəti wɑz dʒɹɛdfəl iðɝ weɪ. ɹæʃənəl pipəl steɪɾ ɪnlænd!

Normally, Bandar Eban was chilly and rainy. Rarely had she felt it this warm. The humidity was dreadful either way. Rational people stayed inland!

ʃi meɪɾ əɹ weɪ daʊn sɛvɹəl stʃɹits, kɹɔsɪŋ θɹu ðə mʌɾ əɾ ɪntɝsɛkʃənz. ðət wɑz ði ɪɹədiməbəl flɔ ʌv bɔɹdwɔks, ɪn əɹ əpɪnjən. ðə loʊkəlz nu wɪtʃ stʃɹits tə kʌɾ əkɹɔs ən wɪtʃ wʌnz wɝ dip ɪn mʌd, bʌt kædzueɪn hæd tə dʒʌs tʃɹæmp əkɹɔs wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi kʊd. ðæts waɪ ʃid hʌntəɾ aʊt ðiz klɑɡz, bɪlt æftɝ ðə tɛɹən staɪl, tə ɡoʊ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃuz. ɪt hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli hɑɹd tə faɪn ə mɝtʃən sɛlɪŋ ðɛm; ðə dəmɑni ɑbviəsli hæd lɪɾəl ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðɛm, ən moʊs pipəl ʃi pæst iðɝ wɛn bɛɹfʊɾ ɪn ðə mʌɾ əɹ nu wɛɹ tə kɹɔs ən kip fɹəm sɔɪlɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃuz.

She made her way down several streets, crossing through the mud at intersections. That was the irredeemable flaw of boardwalks, in her opinion. The locals knew which streets to cut across and which ones were deep in mud, but Cadsuane had to just tramp across wherever she could. That's why she'd hunted out these clogs, built after the Tairen style, to go over her shoes. It had been surprisingly hard to find a merchant selling them; the Domani obviously had little interest in them, and most people she passed either went barefoot in the mud or knew where to cross and keep from soiling their shoes.

hæfweɪ daʊn tə ðə dɑks, ʃi faɪnəli ɹitʃt əɹ dɛstəneɪʃən. ðə faɪn bænɝ flæpɪŋ aʊt fɹʌn pɹoʊkleɪm ði ɪnz neɪm əz ðə wɪnz feɪvɝ, biɾɪŋ əɡɛnst ən ɪnleɪd wʊd fɹʌnt. kædzueɪn meɪɾ əɹ weɪ ɪnsaɪɾ ən tʊk ɔf ðə klɑɡz ɪn ðə mʌɾi ɛntʃɹɪweɪ bɪfɔɹ stɛpɪŋ ʌp ɪndə ði ɪn pɹɑpɝ. ðɛɹ, faɪnəli, ʃi əlaʊd hɝsɛlf tə loʊɝ əɹ hʊd. ɪf ælθɹ ɹændəmli hæpən tə vɪzət ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɪn, ðən hid dʒʌst əv tə hæŋ hɝ.

Halfway down to the docks, she finally reached her destination. The fine banner flapping out front proclaimed the inn's name as The Wind's Favor, beating against an inlaid wood front. Cadsuane made her way inside and took off the clogs in the muddy entryway before stepping up into the inn proper. There, finally, she allowed herself to lower her hood. If al'Thor randomly happened to visit this particular inn, then he'd just have to hang her.

ði ɪnz kɑmən ɹum wɑz dɛkɝeɪɾəd mɔɹ laɪk ə kɪŋz daɪnɪŋ hɔl ðən ə tævɝn. waɪt teɪbəlklɔθs koʊɾəd ðə teɪbəlz, ən ðə vɑɹnɪʃt wʊɾən flɔɹ wɑz mɑp tə ə ʃaɪn. ðə wɔlz wɝ hʌŋ wɪð teɪsfəl stɪl-laɪf peɪntɪŋz - ə boʊl ə fɹuɾ ɑn ðə wɔl bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹ, ə veɪs ə flaʊɝz ɑn ðə wɔl ɑpəzəɾ ɪt. ðə bɑɾəlz ɑn ðə lɛdʒ bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹ wɝ ɔlmoʊst ɔl waɪn, vɛɹi fju bɑɾəlz ə bɹændi əɹ ʌðɝ lɪkɝz.

The inn's common room was decorated more like a king's dining hall than a tavern. White tablecloths coated the tables, and the varnished wooden floor was mopped to a shine. The walls were hung with tasteful still-life paintings - a bowl of fruit on the wall behind the bar, a vase of flowers on the wall opposite it. The bottles on the ledge behind the bar were almost all wine, very few bottles of brandy or other liquors.

ðə slɛndɝ ɪnkipɝ, kwɪlɪn tɑsəl, wɑz ə tɔl, oʊvəl-feɪst ændɔɝən mæn. θɪnɪŋ ɑn tɑp wɪð dɑɹk, ʃɔɹt hɛɹ ət ðə saɪdz ə hɪz hɛd, hi wɔɹ ə fʊl bɪɹd, tʃɹɪmd ʃɔɹt, wɪtʃ wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɔl ɡɹeɪ. hɪz faɪn lævəndɝ koʊt hæd waɪt ɹʌfəl kʌfs pikɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə slivz, bʌɾ i wɔɹ ən ɪnkipɝz eɪpɹən oʊvɝ ðə fɹʌnt. hi dʒɛnɝəli hæd hæd ɡʊɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, bʌt wɑz ɔlsoʊ wɪlɪŋ tə lʊk ɪndə ɪnkwaɪɝiz fəɹ əɹ əmʌŋ ɪz əsoʊsieɪts. ə vɛɹi jusfəl mæn ɪndid.

The slender innkeeper, Quillin Tasil, was a tall, oval-faced Andoran man. Thinning on top with dark, short hair at the sides of his head, he wore a full beard, trimmed short, which was almost all gray. His fine lavender coat had white ruffled cuffs peeking out from the sleeves, but he wore an innkeeper's apron over the front. He generally had had good information, but was also willing to look into inquiries for her among his associates. A very useful man indeed.

hi smaɪld ət kædzueɪn əz ʃi ɛntɝd, waɪpɪŋ ɪz hænz ɑn ə taʊəl. hi dʒɛstʃɝɾ əɹ təwɔɹɾ ə teɪbəl, ðən wɛn bæk tə ðə bɑɹ tə fɛtʃ səm waɪn. kædzueɪn sɛɾəld hɝsɛlf əz tu mɛn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum bɪɡæn tə ɑɹɡju laʊdli. ði ʌðɝ peɪtʃɹənz - oʊnli fɔɹ, tu wɪmən əɾ ə teɪbəl ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪd, tu mɔɹ mɛn ət ðə bɑɹ - peɪd ði ɑɹɡjəmənt noʊ hid. wʌn kʊdn spɛn mʌtʃ taɪm ɪn ɑɹæd dumən wɪθaʊt lɝnɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə fɹikwən flɛɹz ɪn tɛmpɝ. dəmɑni mɛn wɝ əz hɑthɛɾəd əz vɑlkeɪnoʊz, ən moʊs pipəl əɡɹid ðət dəmɑni wɪmən wɝ ðə ɹizən. ðiz tu mɛn dɪd nɑt tɝn tə ə duəl, əz wʊɾə bɪn kɑmən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ ə fju moʊməns, ðən bɪɡæn tə əɡɹi wɪð itʃ ʌðɝ, ðən ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn baɪɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ waɪn. faɪts wɝ kɑmən;

He smiled at Cadsuane as she entered, wiping his hands on a towel. He gestured her toward a table, then went back to the bar to fetch some wine. Cadsuane settled herself as two men on the other side of the room began to argue loudly. The other patrons - only four, two women at a table on the far side, two more men at the bar - paid the argument no heed. One couldn't spend much time in Arad Doman without learning to ignore the frequent flares in temper. Domani men were as hotheaded as volcanoes, and most people agreed that Domani women were the reason. These two men did not turn to a duel, as would have been common in Ebou Dar. Instead, they shouted for a few moments, then began to agree with each other, then insisted on buying one another wine. Fights were common;

blʌdʃɛɾ ɪnfɹikwənt. ɪnʒɝiz wɝ bæd fəɹ bɪznəs.

bloodshed infrequent. Injuries were bad for business.

kwɪlɪn əpɹoʊtʃt, bɛɹɪŋ ə kʌp ʌv waɪn - ɪt wəd bi wʌn ə hɪz faɪnəs vɪntɪdʒɪz. ʃi nɛvɝ ɹɪkwɛstɪd sətʃ fɹəm hɪm, bʌt nɛvɝ kəmpleɪn iðɝ.

Quillin approached, bearing a cup of wine - it would be one of his finest vintages. She never requested such from him, but never complained either.

"mɪstʃɹəs ʃɔɹ," hi sɛd wɪð ɪz æfəbəl vɔɪs, "aɪ wɪʃ aɪd noʊn ɝliɝ ðət jə wɝ bæk ɪn taʊn! ðə fɝst aɪ hɝɾ ʌv ɪt wɑz jəɹ lɛɾɝ!"

"Mistress Shore," he said with his affable voice, "I wish I'd known earlier that you were back in town! The first I heard of it was your letter!"

kædzueɪn tʊk ði ɔfɝd kʌp. "aɪ æm nɑɾ əkʌstəm tə ɡɪvɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn maɪ wɛɹəbaʊts tə ɛvɹi əkweɪntəns, mæstɝ tɑsəl."

Cadsuane took the offered cup. "I am not accustomed to giving reports on my whereabouts to every acquaintance, Master Tasil."

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt, ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," hi sɛd, ən sim kəmplitli ənəfɛndəɾ əɾ əɹ ʃɑɹp ɹɪspɑns.

"Of course not, of course not," he said, and seemed completely unoffended at her sharp response.

ʃid nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ ə ɹaɪz aʊɾ ə hɪm. ðət hæɾ ɔlweɪz meɪɾ əɹ kjʊɹiəs.

She'd never been able to get a rise out of him. That had always made her curious.

"ði ɪn simz tə bi duɪŋ wɛl," ʃi sɛd pəlaɪtli, kɑzɪŋ ɪm tə tɝn ən lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz fju peɪtʃɹənz. ðeɪ simd ənkʌmftəɹbəl tə bi sɪɾɪŋ əɾ ɪmækjulɪt teɪbəlz ətɑp ə ɡlimɪŋ flɔɹ.

"The inn seems to be doing well," she said politely, causing him to turn and look over his few patrons. They seemed uncomfortable to be sitting at immaculate tables atop a gleaming floor.

kædzueɪn wɑzn sɝɾən ɪf ɪt wɑz ði ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪŋ klɛnlinɪs ðət kɛpt pipəl əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɪnz feɪvɝ, əɹ ɪf ɪt wɑz kwɪlɪnz ɪnsɪstəns ɑn nɛvɝ haɪɹɪŋ ɡlimən əɹ mjuzɪʃənz tə pɝfɔɹm. hi kleɪm ðeɪ spɔɪl ði ætməsfɪɹ. əz ʃi wɑtʃt, hi noʊɾəst ðəɾ ə nu peɪtʃɹən ɛntɝd, tʃɹækɪŋ ɪn mʌd.

Cadsuane wasn't certain if it was the intimidating cleanliness that kept people away from The Wind's Favor, or if it was Quillin's insistence on never hiring gleemen or musicians to perform. He claimed they spoiled the atmosphere. As she watched, he noticed that a new patron entered, tracking in mud.

ʃi kəd si kwɪlɪnz fɪŋɡɝz ɪtʃɪŋ tə ɡoʊ skɹʌb ðə flɔɹ.

She could see Quillin's fingers itching to go scrub the floor.

"ju ðɛɹ," kwɪlɪn kɔl tə ðə mæn. "skɹeɪp jəɹ ʃuz bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ ɪn, ɪf jə pliz."

"You there," Quillin called to the man. "Scrape your shoes before coming in, if you please."

ðə mæn fɹoʊz, fɹaʊnɪŋ, bʌt wɛn bæk tə də əz ɪnstʃɹʌktəd. kwɪlɪn saɪɾ ən muvd oʊvɝ tə sɪɾ əɾ əɹ teɪbəl. "fɹæŋkli, mɪstʃɹəs ʃɔɹ, ɪt ɡɛts ə lɪɾəl tu bɪzi hɪɹ leɪtli fəɹ maɪ teɪsts. kæn kip tʃɹæk ʌv ɔl maɪ peɪtʃɹənz səmtaɪmz! pipəl ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt dʒɹɪŋk, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi tə ɡɛt tə ðɛm."

The man froze, frowning, but went back to do as instructed. Quillin sighed and moved over to sit at her table. "Frankly, Mistress Shore, it gets a little too busy here lately for my tastes. Can't keep track of all my patrons sometimes! People go without drink, waiting for me to get to them."

"ju kəd haɪɝ hɛlp," ʃi noʊɾəd. "ə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl əɹ tu."

"You could hire help," she noted. "A serving girl or two."

"wʌt? ən lɛɾ əm əv ɔl ðə fʌn?" hi sɛɾ ɪɾ ɪn ɔl sɪɹiəsnəs.

"What? And let them have all the fun?" He said it in all seriousness.

kædzueɪn tʊk ə sɪp ə hɝ waɪn. ən ɛksələn vɪntɪdʒ ɪndid, pɝhæps ɪkspɛnsɪv ɪnʌf ðəɾ ən ɪn - noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ splɛndəd - ʃʊdn əv hæɾ ɪt ɹɛɾəli əveɪləbəl bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹ. ʃi saɪd.

Cadsuane took a sip of her wine. An excellent vintage indeed, perhaps expensive enough that an inn - no matter how splendid - shouldn't have had it readily available behind the bar. She sighed.

kwɪlɪnz dəmɑni waɪf wɑz wʌn ə ðə moʊst əkɑmplɪʃt sɪlk mɝtʃəns ɪn ðə sɪɾi; mɛni si foʊk vɛsəlz sɔɾ əɹ aʊt pɝsənəli tə tʃɹeɪd wɪð hɝ. kwɪlɪn hæd kɛpt əkaʊns fəɹ ɪz waɪfs bɪznəs fəɹ səm twɛnti jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ i hæd ɹɪtaɪɹd, boʊθ ə ðɛm wɛlθi.

Quillin's Domani wife was one of the most accomplished silk merchants in the city; many Sea Folk vessels sought her out personally to trade with her. Quillin had kept accounts for his wife's business for some twenty years before he had retired, both of them wealthy.

ən wʌɾ i də wɪð ɪt? oʊpən ən ɪn. ɪt hæɾ əpɛɹənli ɔlweɪz bɪn ə dʒɹim ə hɪz. kædzueɪn hæd lɝn lɔŋ əɡoʊ tə stɑp kwɛstʃənɪŋ ði ɑd pɛntʃəns ə pipəl wɪð tu mʌtʃ fɹi taɪm.

And what did he do with it? Open an inn. It had apparently always been a dream of his. Cadsuane had learned long ago to stop questioning the odd penchants of people with too much free time.

"wʌt nuz ə ðə sɪɾi, kwɪlɪn?" ʃi æskt, slaɪɾɪŋ ə smɔl bæɡ ʌv kɔɪnz əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl təwɔɹd hɪm.

"What news of the city, Quillin?" she asked, sliding a small bag of coins across the table toward him.

"mɪstʃɹəs, jə əfɛnd," hi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hænz. "aɪ kʊdn teɪk jəɹ kɔɪn!"

"Mistress, you offend," he said, raising his hands. "I couldn't take your coin!"

ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "aɪ hæv lɪɾəl peɪʃəns fəɹ ɡeɪmz tədeɪ, mæstɝ tɑsəl. ɪf jə doʊnt wɑn ɪt jɝsɛlf, ðən ɡɪv ɪt tə ðə pʊɹ. laɪt noʊz ðəɹ ɑɹ ɪnʌf ə ðoʊz ɪn ðə sɪɾi ðiz deɪz."

She raised an eyebrow. "I have little patience for games today, Master Tasil. If you don't want it yourself, then give it to the poor. Light knows there are enough of those in the city these days."

hi saɪd, bʌt ɹɪlʌktənli pɑkəɾɪd ðə pɝs. pɝhæps ðət wɑz waɪ hɪz kɑmən ɹum wɑz ɔfən ɛmpti; ən ɪnkipɝ u hæd noʊ ɹəɡɑɹd fəɹ mʌni wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ bist. mɛni ʌv ðə kɑmən mɛn wəd faɪn kwɪlɪn əz dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋ əz ði ɪmækjulɪt flɔɹ ən teɪsfəl dɛkɝeɪʃənz.

He sighed, but reluctantly pocketed the purse. Perhaps that was why his common room was often empty; an innkeeper who had no regard for money was a strange beast. Many of the common men would find Quillin as discomforting as the immaculate floor and tasteful decorations.

kwɪlɪn wɑz, haʊɛvɝ, vɛɹi ɡʊd fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. hɪz waɪf ʃɛɹɾ əɹ ɡɑsəp wɪð hɪm. wɪð əɹ feɪs, hi ɑbviəsli nu ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. næmaɪn - hɪz ɛldəs dɔɾɝ - hæd ɡɔn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli tʃuzɪŋ ðə bɹaʊn ən sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪndə ðə laɪbɹɛɹi ðɛɹ. eɪ dəmɑni laɪbɹɛɹiən wɑz nʌθɪŋ ənjuʒəwəl - ðə tɝhɑnə laɪbɹɛɹi ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ɪn ðə wɝld. haʊɛvɝ, næmaɪnz kæʒəwəl, jɛt kin, ʌndɝstændɪŋ ə kɝən ɪvɛns hæd bɪn ɪnʌf ʌv ə kjʊɹiɑsəɾi ðət kædzueɪn hæd fɑloʊd ðə kənɛkʃən, hoʊpɪŋ tə dɪskʌvɝ wɛl-pleɪs pɛɹəns. taɪz sətʃ əz ə dɔɾɝ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɔfən meɪd pipəl eɪmiəbəl təwɔɹɾ ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðət hæd lɛɾ əɹ tə kwɪlɪn. kædzueɪn dɪdn tʃɹʌst ɪm ɪntaɪɝli, bʌt ʃi wɑz fɑn ə hɪm.

Quillin was, however, very good for information. His wife shared her gossip with him. With her face, he obviously knew she was Aes Sedai. Namine - his eldest daughter - had gone to the White Tower, eventually choosing the Brown and settling into the library there. A Domani librarian was nothing unusual - the Terhana library in Bandar Eban was one of the greatest in the world. However, Namine's casual, yet keen, understanding of current events had been enough of a curiosity that Cadsuane had followed the connection, hoping to discover well-placed parents. Ties such as a daughter in the White Tower often made people amiable toward other Aes Sedai. That had led her to Quillin. Cadsuane didn't trust him entirely, but she was fond of him.

"wʌt nuz ə ðə sɪɾi?" kwɪlɪn æskt. ɑnəsli, wʌɾ ɪnkipɝ wɔɹ ə sɪlk ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd vɛs bɪniθ ɪz eɪpɹən? noʊ wʌndɝ pipəl faʊn ði ɪn stʃɹeɪnʒ. "wɛɹ ʃəɾ aɪ stɑɹt? ðəɹ əz ɔlmoʊs bɪn tu mʌtʃ tə kip tʃɹæk ə leɪtli!"

"What news of the city?" Quillin asked. Honestly, what innkeeper wore a silk embroidered vest beneath his apron? No wonder people found the inn strange. "Where should I start? There has almost been too much to keep track of lately!"

"stɑɹt wɪð ælsələm," kædzueɪn sɛd, sɪpɪŋ əɹ waɪn. "wɛn wɑz i læst sin?"

"Start with Alsalam," Cadsuane said, sipping her wine. "When was he last seen?"

"baɪ kɹɛɾəbəl wɪtnəsəz, əɹ baɪ hɪɹseɪ?"

"By credible witnesses, or by hearsay?"

"tɛl mi boʊθ."

"Tell me both."

"ðɛɹ əv bɪn lɛsɝ wɪndbɔɹn ən mɝtʃəns u kleɪm tə hæv ɹəsiv pɝsənəl kəmjunəkeɪʃən fɹəm ðə kɪŋ əz ɹisənli əz ə wik əɡoʊ, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌɾ aɪ ɹəɡɑɹd sətʃ kleɪmz wɪð skɛptɪsɪzəm. vɛɹi sun æftɝ ðə kɪŋz . . . haɪeɪɾəs bɪɡæn jə kəd faɪn fɔɹdʒ lɛɾɝz kleɪmɪŋ tə dɪkteɪɾ ɪz wɪʃɪz. aɪ hæv sin səm fju sɛts ʌv ɔɹɾɝz wɪð maɪ oʊn aɪz ðəɾ aɪ tʃɹʌst - ɔɹ, ət list, aɪ tʃɹʌs ðə sil ɑn əm - bʌt ðə kɪŋ hɪmsɛlf? aɪd seɪ ɪts bɪn ɔlmoʊs hæf ə jɪɹ sɪns ɛniwʌn aɪ kən vaʊtʃ fəɹ əz sin hɪm."

"There have been lesser windborn and merchants who claim to have received personal communication from the King as recently as a week ago, my Lady, but I regard such claims with skepticism. Very soon after the King's . . . hiatus began you could find forged letters claiming to dictate his wishes. I have seen some few sets of orders with my own eyes that I trust - or, at least, I trust the seal on them - but the King himself? I'd say it has been almost half a year since anyone I can vouch for has seen him."

"hɪz wɛɹəbaʊts, ðɛn?"

"His whereabouts, then?"

ði ɪnkipɝ ʃɹʌɡd, lʊkɪŋ əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk. "fɔɹ ə waɪl, wi wɝ sɝɾən ðət ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns wɑz bɪhaɪn ðə dɪsəpɪɹəns. ðeɪ ɹɛɹli lɛt ðə kɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ saɪt, ən wɪð ðə tʃɹʌbəlz tə ðə saʊθ, wi ɔl əsum ðeɪd teɪkən ɪz mædʒəsti tə seɪfti."

The innkeeper shrugged, looking apologetic. "For a while, we were certain that the Council of Merchants was behind the disappearance. They rarely let the King out of their sight, and with the troubles to the south, we all assumed they'd taken His Majesty to safety."

"bʌt?"

"But?"

"bʌt maɪ sɔɹsəz," ðət mɛn ɪz waɪf, "ɑɹən kənvɪnst ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns əz bɪn tu dɪsɔɹɡənaɪz leɪtli, itʃ mɛmbɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ðɛɹ oʊn tʃʌŋk ʌv ɑɹæd dumən fɹəm ənɹævəlɪŋ. ɪf ðeɪd hæd ðə kɪŋ, ðeɪɾ əv ɹɪvild ɪm baɪ naʊ."

"But my sources," that meant his wife, "aren't convinced any longer. The Council of Merchants has been too disorganized lately, each member trying to keep their own chunk of Arad Doman from unraveling. If they'd had the King, they'd have revealed him by now."

kædzueɪn tæp ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ kʌp wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl, ənɔɪd. kəd ðəɹ bi tʃɹuθ, ðɛn, tə ði ælθɹ bɔɪz bɪlif ðət wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæɾ ælsələm? "wʌɾ ɛls?"

Cadsuane tapped the side of her cup with a fingernail, annoyed. Could there be truth, then, to the al'Thor boy's belief that one of the Forsaken had Alsalam? "What else?"

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ il ɪn ðə sɪɾi, leɪɾi," kwɪlɪn sɛd, skɹʌbɪŋ əɾ ən ɪnvɪzəbəl spɑɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp.

"There are Aiel in the city, Lady," Quillin said, scrubbing at an invisible spot on the tabletop.

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə flæt stɛɹ. "aɪ hædnt noʊɾəst."

She gave him a flat stare. "I hadn't noticed."

hi tʃʌkəld. "jɛs, jɛs, ɑbviəs, aɪ səpoʊz. bʌt ði ɪɡzæk nʌmbɝ ɪn ði ɛɹiə ɪz twɛnti-fɔɹ θaʊzənd. səm seɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz əm hɪɹ dʒʌs tə pɹuv ɪz paʊɝ ən əθɔɹəɾi. æftɝ ɔl, hu ɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv il dɪstʃɹɪbjuɾɪŋ fud? hæf ðə pʊɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɑɹ tu fɹaɪɾənd tə ɡoʊ tə ðə hændaʊts, fəɹ fɪɹ ði il əv juz səm ə ðɛɹ pɔɪzənz ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪn."

He chuckled. "Yes, yes, obvious, I suppose. But the exact number in the area is twenty-four thousand. Some say the Dragon Reborn has them here just to prove his power and authority. After all, who ever heard of Aiel distributing food? Half the poor in the city are too frightened to go to the handouts, for fear the Aiel have used some of their poisons on the grain."

"il pɔɪzənz?" ʃid nɛvɝ hɝd ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɹumɝ bɪfɔɹ.

"Aiel poisons?" She'd never heard that particular rumor before.

kwɪlɪn nɑɾəd. "sʌm kleɪm ðəɾ əz ðə ɹizən fəɹ ðə fud spɔɪlɑdʒɪz, maɪ leɪɾi."

Quillin nodded. "Some claim that as the reason for the food spoilages, my Lady."

"bʌt fud wɑz spɔɪlɪŋ ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ði il ɝaɪvd, wɑzn ɪt?"

"But food was spoiling in the country long before the Aiel arrived, wasn't it?"

"jɛs, jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs," kwɪlɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪt kən bi hɑɹd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ θɪŋz laɪk ðəɾ ɪn ðə feɪs ə soʊ mʌtʃ bæd ɡɹeɪn. bɪsaɪdz, spɔɪlədʒ əz ɡɹoʊn mʌtʃ wɝs sɪns ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɝaɪvd."

"Yes, yes, of course," Quillin said. "But it can be hard to remember things like that in the face of so much bad grain. Besides, spoilage has grown much worse since the Lord Dragon arrived."

kædzueɪn kʌvɝɾ əɹ fɹaʊn baɪ teɪkɪŋ ə sɪp ʌv waɪn. ɪt hæd ɡɹoʊn wɝs wɪð ælθɹz ɝaɪvəl?

Cadsuane covered her frown by taking a sip of wine. It had grown worse with al'Thor's arrival?

wɑz ðət dʒʌst ɹumɝ, əɹ wɑz ɪt ðə tʃɹuθ? ʃi loʊɝɾ əɹ kʌp. "æn ði ʌðɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ əkɝənsɪz ɪn ðə sɪɾi?" ʃi æskt kɛɹfəli, tə si wʌt ʃi kəd dɪskʌvɝ.

Was that just rumor, or was it the truth? She lowered her cup. "And the other strange occurrences in the city?" she asked carefully, to see what she could discover.

"juv hɝɾ ə ðoʊz, ðɛn?" kwɪlɪn sɛd, linɪŋ ɪn. "pipəl doʊn laɪk tə spik ə ðɛm, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt maɪ sɔɹsəz hɪɹ θɪŋz. stɪlbɔɹn tʃɪlʒɹən, mɛn daɪɪŋ fɹəm fɔlz ðət ʃəd bɛɹli hæv kɑzd ə bɹuz, stoʊnz tɑpəlɪŋ fɹəm bɪldɪŋz ən stʃɹaɪkɪŋ wɪmən dɛɾ əz ðeɪ tʃɹeɪd. deɪnʒɝəs taɪmz, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪ heɪt tə pæs ɑn mɪɹ hɪɹseɪ, bʌɾ aɪv sin ðə nʌmbɝz maɪsɛlf!"

"You've heard of those, then?" Quillin said, leaning in. "People don't like to speak of them, of course, but my sources hear things. Stillborn children, men dying from falls that should barely have caused a bruise, stones toppling from buildings and striking women dead as they trade. Dangerous times, my Lady. I hate to pass on mere hearsay, but I've seen the numbers myself!"

ði ɪvɛns wɝ nɑt, ɪn ðɛmsɛlvz, ʌnɪkspɛktɪd. "ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ ɑɹ ðə bælənsəz."

The events were not, in themselves, unexpected. "Of course, there are the balances."

"bælənsəz?"

"Balances?"

"mɛɹɪdʒɪz ɑn ðə ɹaɪz," ʃi sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ə hænd, "tʃɪlʒɹən u ɪnkaʊntɝ waɪl bists bʌɾ ɪskeɪp ənhɑɹmd, ʌnɪkspɛktɪd fɔɹtʃənz dɪskʌvɝd bɪniθ ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz ʌv ə pɔpɝz hoʊm. ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ."

"Marriages on the rise," she said, waving a hand, "children who encounter wild beasts but escape unharmed, unexpected fortunes discovered beneath the floorboards of a pauper's home. That sort of thing."

"ðæt sɝɾənli wəd bi naɪs," kwɪlɪn sɛd, tʃʌklɪŋ. "wi kən wɪʃ ən hoʊp, maɪ leɪɾi."

"That certainly would be nice," Quillin said, chuckling. "We can wish and hope, my Lady."

"juv hɝd noʊ sətʃ stɔɹiz?" kædzueɪn æskt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz.

"You've heard no such stories?" Cadsuane asked with surprise.

"noʊ, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪ kən æsk ɝaʊnd, ɪf jə wɪʃ."

"No, my Lady. I can ask around, if you wish."

"du soʊ." ælθɹ wɑz tɑvɝən, bʌt ðə pæɾɝn wɑz ə θɪŋ ə bæləns. fəɹ ɛvɹi æksədɛntəl dɛθ kɑz baɪ ɹændz pɹɛzəns ɪn ə sɪɾi, ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə mɝækjələs sɝvaɪvəl.

"Do so." Al'Thor was ta'veren, but the Pattern was a thing of balance. For every accidental death caused by Rand's presence in a city, there was always a miraculous survival.

wʌɾ ɪt min ɪf ðət wɑz bɹeɪkɪŋ daʊn?

What did it mean if that was breaking down?

ʃi wɛn ɑn tə spəsɪfɪk kwɛstʃənz fəɹ kwɪlɪn, ðə wɛɹəbaʊts ə ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl ət ðə tɑp ə ðə lɪst. ʃi nu ðət ði ælθɹ bɔɪ wɑntəd tə kæptʃɝ əm ɔl; ɪf ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əbaʊt ðɛɹ loʊkeɪʃənz ðəɾ i dɪdn hæv, ɪt kəd bi vɛɹi jusfəl. ʃi ɔlsoʊ æskt kwɪlɪn tə faɪn aʊt ði ɛkənɑmɪk sɪtʃueɪʃən ə ði ʌðɝ meɪdʒɝ dəmɑni sɪɾiz ən səplaɪ ɛni nuz ə ɹɛbəl fækʃənz əɹ tæɹɑbənɝz stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝ.

She went on to specific questions for Quillin, the whereabouts of the members of the merchant council at the top of the list. She knew that the al'Thor boy wanted to capture them all; if she could get information about their locations that he didn't have, it could be very useful. She also asked Quillin to find out the economic situation of the other major Domani cities and supply any news of rebel factions or Taraboners striking across the border.

əz ʃi lɛf ði ɪn - ɹɪlʌktənli ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hʊɾ ən stɛpɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə mʌɡi æftɝnun - ʃi faʊn ðət kwɪlɪnz wɝdz hæd lɛft əɹ wɪð mɔɹ kwɛstʃənz ðən ʃid hæd wən ʃid kʌm.

As she left the inn - reluctantly raising her hood and stepping back into the muggy afternoon - she found that Quillin's words had left her with more questions than she'd had when she'd come.

ɪt lʊk laɪk ɹeɪn. ʌv kɔɹs, ðət wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə weɪ ɪt lʊk leɪtli. oʊvɝkæst ən dʒɹɪɹi, wɪð ə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ ən klaʊdz ðət blɛd təɡɛðɝ ɪn ə junəfɔɹm heɪz. ət list ɪt hæɾ æktʃəli  ɹeɪn ðə pɹiviəs naɪt; fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðət meɪd ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ mɔɹ bɛɹəbəl. əz ɪf ɪt wɝ mɔɹ nætʃɹəl, əlaʊɪŋ əɹ tə pɹitɛn ðət ðə pɝpɛtʃuəl ɡlum wɑzn ənʌðɝ saɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz stɝɪŋ. hi hæd wɪðɝd ðə pipəl wɪð ə dʒɹaʊt, hi hæd fɹoʊzən əm wɪð ə sʌɾən wɪntɝ, ən naʊ hi sim dɪtɝmən tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm θɹu ʃɪɹ mɛlənkɑli.

It looked like rain. Of course, that was always the way it looked lately. Overcast and dreary, with a gray sky and clouds that bled together in a uniform haze. At least it had actually rained the previous night; for some reason, that made the overcast sky more bearable. As if it were more natural, allowing her to pretend that the perpetual gloom wasn't another sign of the Dark One's stirring. He had withered the people with a drought, he had frozen them with a sudden winter, and now he seemed determined to destroy them through sheer melancholy.

kædzueɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, tæpɪŋ əɹ klɑɡz tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ stɝɾəli əfɪkst, ðən wɔkt ɑntu ðə mʌɾid bɔɹdwɔk ən meɪɾ əɹ weɪ daʊn təwɔɹd ðə dɑks. ʃi wəd si dʒʌs haʊ ækjɝət ðiz ɹumɝz əbaʊt spɔɪlədʒ wɝ. hæd ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪvɛns sɝaʊndɪŋ ælθɹ ɹɪli ɡɹoʊn mɔɹ dɪstʃɹʌktɪv, əɹ wɑz ʃi dʒʌst əlaʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə faɪnd wʌt ʃi fɪɹd?

Cadsuane shook her head, tapping her clogs to make sure they were sturdily affixed, then walked onto the muddied boardwalk and made her way down toward the docks. She would see just how accurate these rumors about spoilage were. Had the strange events surrounding al'Thor really grown more destructive, or was she just allowing herself to find what she feared?

ælθɹ. ʃi hæd tə feɪs ðə tʃɹuθ: ʃi hæd bʌŋɡəld əɹ hænlɪŋ ə hɪm. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hædn meɪɾ ɛni mɪsteɪks wɪð ðə meɪl æɾəm, wʌtɛvɝ ælθɹ kleɪmd. huɛvɝ hæd stoʊlən ðə kɑlɝ hæd bɪn ɪksiɾɪŋli paʊɝfəl ən kɹæfti. ɛniwʌn keɪpəbəl ə sətʃ ə fit kəd dʒʌst əz izəli hæv fɛtʃt ənʌðɝ meɪl æɾəm fɹəm ðə sintʃæn. ðeɪ wɝ laɪkli tə hæv plɛnti ʌv ðɛm.

Al'Thor. She had to face the truth: she had bungled her handling of him. Of course, she hadn't made any mistakes with the male a'dam, whatever al'Thor claimed. Whoever had stolen the collar had been exceedingly powerful and crafty. Anyone capable of such a feat could just as easily have fetched another male a'dam from the Seanchan. They were likely to have plenty of them.

noʊ, ði æɾəm hæd bɪn teɪkən fɹəm əɹ oʊn ɹum ɪn ən ɛfɝt tə saʊ dɪstʃɹʌst; ʌv ðət ʃi wɑz sɝɾən. pɝhæps, ivən, ðə θɛf hæd bɪn ɪntɛndəd tə mæsk sʌmθɪŋ ɛls: ðə ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ə ðə fɪɡjɝin tə ælθɹ. hɪz tɛmpɹəmən hæd bɪkʌm soʊ dɑɹk, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ wʌt dɪstʃɹʌkʃən i kəd kɑz wɪð ðæt.

No, the a'dam had been taken from her own room in an effort to sow distrust; of that she was certain. Perhaps, even, the theft had been intended to mask something else: the returning of the figurine to al'Thor. His temperament had become so dark, there was no telling what destruction he could cause with that.

ðə pʊɹ, fulɪʃ bɔɪ. hi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv hæd tə sʌfɝ kəlɹɪŋ ət ðə hænz ʌv wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən; ðət wəɾ oʊnli ɹimaɪn ɪm ə ðə taɪmz i hæd bɪn biɾən ən keɪdʒ baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt wəd meɪk əɹ dʒɑb mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt. ɪf nɑɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl.

The poor, foolish boy. He should never have had to suffer collaring at the hands of one of the Forsaken; that would only remind him of the times he had been beaten and caged by Aes Sedai. It would make her job more difficult. If not impossible.

ðət wɑz ðə kwɛstʃən ʃi hæd tə feɪs naʊ. wɑz i bɪɑn seɪvɪŋ? wɑz ɪt tu leɪt tə tʃeɪnʒ hɪm?

That was the question she had to face now. Was he beyond saving? Was it too late to change him?

ən ɪf ɪt wɑz, wʌt - ɪf ɛniθɪŋ - kəd ʃi du? ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd tə mit ðə dɑɹk wʌn ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ɪf i dɪd nɑt, ɔl wɑz lɔst. bʌt wʌɾ ɪf əlaʊɪŋ ɪm tə mit ðə dɑɹk wʌn wəd bi ikwəli dɪzæstʃɹəs?

And if it was, what - if anything - could she do? The Dragon Reborn had to meet the Dark One at Shayol Ghul. If he did not, all was lost. But what if allowing him to meet the Dark One would be equally disastrous?

noʊ. ʃi ɹəfjuz tə bɪliv ðət ðɛɹ bæɾəl hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn lɔst. ðəɹ hæd tə bi sʌmθɪŋ ðət kəd bi dʌn tə tʃeɪnʒ ælθɹz dɝɛkʃən. bʌt wʌt?

No. She refused to believe that their battle had already been lost. There had to be something that could be done to change al'Thor's direction. But what?

ælθɹ hædn ɹiæktəd laɪk moʊs pɛzəns sʌɾənli ɡɹæntəd paʊɝ; hi hædnt ɡɹoʊn sɛlfɪʃ əɹ pɛɾi. hi hædn hɔɹɾɪd wɛlθ, nɔɹ hæɾ i stʃɹʌk wɪð tʃaɪldɪʃ vɛnʒəns əɡɛnst ɛni hu hæd slaɪɾɪd ɪm ɪn ɪz juθ. ɪndid, ðəɹ hæɾ æktʃəli  bɪn ə wɪzdəm tə mɛni ʌv ɪz dɪsɪʒənz - ðə wʌnz ðət dɪdn ɪnvɑlv ɡælɪvæntɪŋ ɪndə deɪnʒɝ.

Al'Thor hadn't reacted like most peasants suddenly granted power; he hadn't grown selfish or petty. He hadn't hoarded wealth, nor had he struck with childish vengeance against any who had slighted him in his youth. Indeed, there had actually been a wisdom to many of his decisions - the ones that didn't involve gallivanting into danger.

kædzueɪn kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə bɔɹdwɔk, pæsɪŋ dəmɑni ɹɛfjudʒiz ɪn ðɛɹ ɪŋkɔŋɹuəsli bɹaɪt kloʊðɪŋ. ʃi əkeɪʒənəli hæd tə stɛp ɝaʊn klʌstɝz ə ðɛm sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə dæmp lɔɡz, ən ɪmpɹɑmptu kæmp ɡɹoʊɪŋ ʌp ɝaʊn ðə maʊθ tə ən æliweɪ əɹ ði ənjuz saɪd dɔɹ ʌv ə bɪldɪŋ. nʌn meɪd weɪ fəɹ hɝ. wʌt ɡʊd wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs ɪf jə kʌvɝɾ ɪɾ ʌp? ðɪs sɪɾi wɑz dʒʌs tu pækt.

Cadsuane continued down the boardwalk, passing Domani refugees in their incongruously bright clothing. She occasionally had to step around clusters of them sitting on the damp logs, an impromptu camp growing up around the mouth to an alleyway or the unused side door of a building. None made way for her. What good was an Aes Sedai face if you covered it up? This city was just too packed.

kædzueɪn sloʊd nɪɹ ə ɹoʊ ʌv pɛnəns wɪtʃ spɛld aʊt ðə neɪm ə ðə dɑk ɹɛdʒɪstʃɹɑɹ. ðə dɑks ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ dʒʌst əhɛd, laɪn baɪ twaɪs əz mɛni si foʊk ʃɪps əz bɪfɔɹ, mɛni ʌv əm ɹeɪkɝz, ðə lɑɹdʒəst ə si foʊk vɛsəlz. mɔɹ ðən ə fju wɝ kənvɝɾɪd sintʃæn ʃɪps, laɪkli stoʊlən fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə mæs ɪskeɪp ə ʃɔɹt waɪl bæk.

Cadsuane slowed near a row of pennants which spelled out the name of the dock registrar. The docks themselves were just ahead, lined by twice as many Sea Folk ships as before, many of them rakers, the largest of Sea Folk vessels. More than a few were converted Seanchan ships, likely stolen from Ebou Dar during the mass escape a short while back.

ðə dɑks wɝ kɹaʊɾəd wɪð pipəl iɡɝ fəɹ ɡɹeɪn. ðə kɹaʊdz dʒɑsəld ən jɛld, nɑt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɔl wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðə "pɔɪzənz" kwɪlɪn hæd mɛnʃənd. ʌv kɔɹs, stɑɹveɪʃən kəɾ oʊvɝkʌm ə ɡɹeɪt nʌmbɝ ə fɪɹz. dɑk wɝkɝz kəntʃɹoʊl ðə kɹaʊdz; əmʌŋ əm wɝ il ɪn bɹaʊn keɪɾɪnsɝ, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ spɪɹz ən ɡlɛɹɪŋ əz oʊnli il kʊd. ðəɹ ɔlsoʊ əpɪɹd tə bi ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə mɝtʃəns ɑn ðə dɑks, pɹɑbli hoʊpɪŋ tə sɪkjʊɹ səm ə ðə hændaʊts fəɹ stɔɹədʒ ən leɪɾɝ seɪl.

The docks were crowded with people eager for grain. The crowds jostled and yelled, not looking at all worried about the "poisons" Quillin had mentioned. Of course, starvation could overcome a great number of fears. Dock workers controlled the crowds; among them were Aiel in brown cadin'sor, holding their spears and glaring as only Aiel could. There also appeared to be a fair number of merchants on the docks, probably hoping to secure some of the handouts for storage and later sale.

ðə dɑks lʊk mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ hæɾ ɛvɹi deɪ sɪns ælθɹz ɝaɪvəl. wʌt hæd meɪɾ əɹ pɔz?

The docks looked much as they had every day since al'Thor's arrival. What had made her pause?

ðəɹ sim tə bi ə pɹɪklɪŋ sɛnseɪʃən ɑn əɹ bæk, əz ɪf. . . .

There seemed to be a prickling sensation on her back, as if. . . .

ʃi spʌn tə faɪn ə pɹəsɛʃən ɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə mʌɾi stʃɹit. ælθɹ sæt pɹaʊdli ɑn ɪz dɑɹk ɡɛldɪŋ, hɪz kloʊðɪŋ kʌlɝd tə mætʃ, wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl ɹɛɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. əz juʒəwəl, hi lɛɾ ə skɔɹ ə soʊlʒɝz, ædvaɪzɝz ən ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ nʌmbɝ ə dəmɑni sɪkɑfæns.

She spun to find a procession riding down the muddy street. Al'Thor sat proudly on his dark gelding, his clothing colored to match, with only a little red embroidery. As usual, he led a score of soldiers, advisors and a growing number of Domani sycophants.

ʃi sim tə ɪnkaʊntɝ ɪm vɛɹi fɹikwənli tʃɹævlɪŋ ðə stʃɹits. ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə hoʊld əɹ ɡɹaʊnd, nɑt ʃaɪɪŋ əweɪ ɪndə ən æli, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd pʊl əɹ hʊd daʊn ə lɪɾəl loʊɝ tə ʃeɪɾ əɹ feɪs. ælθɹ ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ðəɾ i ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əɹ əz i ɹoʊd dʒʌst ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. hi sim tʃɹʌbəl baɪ hɪz oʊn θɔts, əz i ɔfən wɑz. ʃi wɑntəd tə jɛl əɾ ɪm ðəɾ i niɾəd tə muv mɔɹ kwɪkli, sɪkjʊɹ ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ɑɹæd dumən ən muv ɑn, bʌt ʃi hɛld əɹ tʌŋ. ʃi wəd nɑt lɛɾ əɹ nɪɹli θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ə laɪf ɛnd wɪð ən ɛksəkjuʃən ət ðə hænz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!

She seemed to encounter him very frequently traveling the streets. She forced herself to hold her ground, not shying away into an alley, though she did pull her hood down a little lower to shade her face. Al'Thor gave no sign that he recognized her as he rode just in front of her. He seemed troubled by his own thoughts, as he often was. She wanted to yell at him that he needed to move more quickly, secure the crown of Arad Doman and move on, but she held her tongue. She would not let her nearly three hundred years of life end with an execution at the hands of the Dragon Reborn!

hɪz ɹɛɾənu pæst. əz bɪfɔɹ, wən ʃi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, ʃi θɔt ʃi sɔ . . . fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ . . . dɑɹknəs ɝaʊn hɪm, laɪk tu mʌtʃ ʃeɪd fɹəm ðə klaʊdz əbʌv. wɛnɛvɝ ʃi lʊk dɝɛkli ət hɪm, ɪt vænɪʃt - ɪn fækt, wɛnɛvɝ ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə si ɪt, ʃi kʊdn meɪk ɪɾ aʊt. ɪɾ oʊnli əpɪɹd wən ʃi sɔ hɪm ɪndɝɛkli, ən baɪ hæpənstæns.

His retinue passed. As before, when she turned away from him, she thought she saw . . . from the corner of her eye . . . darkness around him, like too much shade from the clouds above. Whenever she looked directly at him, it vanished - in fact, whenever she tried to see it, she couldn't make it out. It only appeared when she saw him indirectly, and by happenstance.

ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɹɛɾ əɹ hɝɾ ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ ɪn ɔl ə hɝ jɪɹz. tə si ɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn tɛɹəfaɪd hɝ. ðɪs hæd ɡɹoʊn bɪɡɝ ðən əɹ pɹaɪd, mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən əɹ feɪljɝz. noʊ. ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ʃi wɑz. ɡaɪɾɪŋ ælθɹ wɑzn laɪk ɡaɪɾɪŋ ə ɡæləpɪŋ hɔɹs, ɪt wɑz laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡaɪɾ ə dip si tɛmpəst ɪtsɛlf!

She had never read or heard of such a thing in all of her years. To see it around the Dragon Reborn terrified her. This had grown bigger than her pride, much larger than her failures. No. It had always been larger than she was. Guiding al'Thor wasn't like guiding a galloping horse, it was like trying to guide a deep sea tempest itself!

ʃi wəd nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪz kɔɹs. hi dɪdn tʃɹʌst ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən wɪð ɡʊd ɹizən.

She would never be able to change his course. He didn't trust Aes Sedai, and with good reason.

hi dɪdn sim tə tʃɹʌst ɛniwʌn, seɪv pɝhæps fəɹ mɪn - bʌt mɪn hæd ɹɪzɪstɪɾ ɛvɹi ətɛmp ðət kædzueɪn hæd meɪɾ əɾ ɪnvɑlvɪŋ hɝ. ðə ɡɝl wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz ælθɹ.

He didn't seem to trust anyone, save perhaps for Min - but Min had resisted every attempt that Cadsuane had made at involving her. The girl was almost as bad as al'Thor.

vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə dɑks wɑz jusləs. tɔkɪŋ tə hɝ ɪnfɔɹməns wɑz jusləs. ɪf ʃi dɪdn də sʌmθɪŋ sun, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dumd. bʌt wʌt? ʃi lin bæk əɡɛns ðə bɪldɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ, tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ bænɝz bloʊɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, pɔɪntɪŋ nɔɹθ. təwɔɹd ðə blaɪɾ ən ælθɹz ʌltəmət dɛstəni.

Visiting the docks was useless. Talking to her informants was useless. If she didn't do something soon, they were all doomed. But what? She leaned back against the building behind her, triangular banners blowing in front of her, pointing north. Toward the Blight and al'Thor's ultimate destiny.

ən aɪdiə stʃɹʌk hɝ. ʃi sizd ɪt laɪk ə dʒɹaʊnɪŋ wʊmən ɪn ðə tʃɝnɪŋ weɪvz. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ətætʃt tə, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz əɹ oʊnli hoʊp.

An idea struck her. She seized it like a drowning woman in the churning waves. She didn't know what it was attached to, but it was her only hope.

ʃi spʌn ɑn əɹ hilz ən hɝid bæk ðə weɪ ʃi hæd kʌm, hɝ hɛd baʊd, bɛɹli dɛɹɪŋ tə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ əɹ plæn. ɪt kəd feɪl soʊ izəli. ɪf ælθɹ ɹɪli wɑz əz dɑməneɪɾəd baɪ hɪz ɹeɪdʒ əz ʃi fɪɹd, ðən ivən ðɪs wəd nɑt hɛlp hɪm.

She spun on her heels and hurried back the way she had come, her head bowed, barely daring to think about her plan. It could fail so easily. If al'Thor really was as dominated by his rage as she feared, then even this would not help him.

bʌɾ ɪf i ɹɪli wɑz ðət fɑɹ ɡɔn, ðən ðəɹ wɑzn ɛniθɪŋ ðət wəd hɛlp hɪm. ðət mɛnt ʃi hæd nʌθɪŋ tə luz. nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf.

But if he really was that far gone, then there wasn't anything that would help him. That meant she had nothing to lose. Nothing but the world itself.

pʊʃɪŋ əɹ weɪ θɹu kɹaʊdz ən əkeɪʒənəli teɪkɪŋ tə ðə mʌɾi stʃɹit tə əvɔɪd ðɛm, ʃi ɝaɪvd ət ðə mænʃən. səm il hæd teɪkən ðə kæmp wɛɹ dɑbɹeɪnz ɑɹmmɪn hæd steɪdʒd əntɪl ɪz wɪðdʒɹɔəl. ðeɪ kæmpt ɔl əbaʊt, səm ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnz, səm ɪn ə wɪŋ ə ðə mænʃən, ʌðɝz ɪn nɪɹbaɪ bɪldɪŋz.

Pushing her way through crowds and occasionally taking to the muddy street to avoid them, she arrived at the mansion. Some Aiel had taken the camp where Dobraine's armsmen had staged until his withdrawal. They camped all about, some on the grounds, some in a wing of the mansion, others in nearby buildings.

kædzueɪn meɪɾ əɹ weɪ tə ðə wɪŋ ðət bɪlɔŋ tə ði il, ən ʃi wɑz nɑt stɑpt. ʃi ɛndʒɔɪd pɹɪvlədʒəz əmʌŋ ði il ðət nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz hæd bɪn ɡɪvən. ʃi faʊn sɔɹɪliə ən ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz ɪn kɑnfɝəns ɪn wʌn ə ðə laɪbɹɛɹiz. ðeɪ wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ʌv kɔɹs.

Cadsuane made her way to the wing that belonged to the Aiel, and she was not stopped. She enjoyed privileges among the Aiel that none of the other sisters had been given. She found Sorilea and the other Wise Ones in conference in one of the libraries. They were sitting on the floor, of course.

sɔɹɪliə nɑɾəd tə kædzueɪn əz ʃi ɛntɝd. ʃi wɑz ɔl boʊn, θɪn ən lɛðɝi, jɛt nɛvɝ kəɾ ə pɝsən θɪŋk əɹ fɹeɪl. nɑt wɪð ðoʊz aɪz, sɛɾ ɪndə ə feɪs ðæt, dɪspaɪt biɪŋ wɔɹn baɪ wɪn ən sʌn, wɑz tu jʌŋ fəɹ əɹ eɪdʒ. haʊ wɑz ɪt ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz kəd lɪv soʊ lɔŋ, jɛt nɑɾ əbteɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ eɪɡləsnəs? ðət wɑz ə kwɛstʃən kædzueɪn hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə ænsɝ.

Sorilea nodded to Cadsuane as she entered. She was all bone, thin and leathery, yet never could a person think her frail. Not with those eyes, set into a face that, despite being worn by wind and sun, was too young for her age. How was it that the Wise Ones could live so long, yet not obtain the Aes Sedai agelessness? That was a question Cadsuane had not been able to answer.

ʃi loʊɝɾ əɹ hʊɾ ən dʒɔɪn ðə waɪz wʌnz, siɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ɛʃuɪŋ kʊʃənz.

She lowered her hood and joined the Wise Ones, seating herself on the floor, eschewing cushions.

ʃi lʊk sɔɹɪliə ɪn ði aɪz. "aɪ hæv feɪld," ʃi sɛd.

She looked Sorilea in the eyes. "I have failed," she said.

ðə waɪz wʌn nɑɾəd, əz ɪf ʃi hæd θɔt ðɪs seɪm θɪŋ. kædzueɪn fɔɹs hɝsɛlf nɑt tə ʃoʊ hɝ ənɔɪəns.

The Wise One nodded, as if she had thought this same thing. Cadsuane forced herself not to show her annoyance.

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ʃeɪm ɪn feɪljɝ," bɛɹ sɛd, "wɛn ðət feɪljɝ wɑz ðə fɔlt ʌv ənʌðɝ."

"There is no shame in failure," Bair said, "when that failure was the fault of another."

æmɪz nɑɾəd. "ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɪz stʌbɝn bɪɑn ɔl mɛn, kædzueɪn sədaɪ. juv noʊ toʊ təwɔɹɾ ʌs."

Amys nodded. "The Car'a'carn is stubborn beyond all men, Cadsuane Sedai. You have no toh toward us."

"ʃeɪm əɹ toʊ," kædzueɪn sɛd, "ɪt wɪl ɔl bi ɪɹɛləvən sun. bʌɾ aɪ hæv ə plæn. wɪl jə hɛlp mi?"

"Shame or toh," Cadsuane said, "it will all be irrelevant soon. But I have a plan. Will you help me?"

ðə waɪz wʌnz ʃɛɹɾ ə lʊk əmʌŋ ðɛm.

The Wise Ones shared a look among them.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs plæn?" sɔɹɪliə æskt.

"What is this plan?" Sorilea asked.

kædzueɪn smaɪld, ðən bɪɡæn tə ɪkspleɪn.

Cadsuane smiled, then began to explain.

ɹænd ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, wɑtʃɪŋ kædzueɪn skʌɾəl əweɪ. ʃi pɹɑbli θɔt ðəɾ i hædnt noʊɾəst əɹ haɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit. ðə kloʊk hɪɾ əɹ feɪs, bʌt nʌθɪŋ kəd kənsil ðət sɛlf-əʃʊɹd pɑstʃɝ, nɑɾ ivən ðə klʌmzi fʊtɡɪɹ. ivən əz ʃi hɝid, ʃi simd ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl, ən ʌðɝz muvd aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ ɹiflɛksɪvli.

Rand glanced over his shoulder, watching Cadsuane scuttle away. She probably thought that he hadn't noticed her hiding there at the side of the street. The cloak hid her face, but nothing could conceal that self-assured posture, not even the clumsy footgear. Even as she hurried, she seemed in control, and others moved out of her way reflexively.

ʃi flɝɾɪd wɪð ɪz pɹoʊəbɪʃən, fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm θɹu ðə taʊn laɪk ðɪs. haʊɛvɝ, ʃi hæd nɑt ʃoʊn ɪm əɹ feɪs, ən soʊ hi lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ. ɪt hæd pɹɑbli bɪn ə pʊɹ muv tə ɛɡzaɪl əɹ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk naʊ. hi wəd dʒʌst əv tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪz tɛmpɝ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ. kip ɪt ɹæpt ɪn aɪs, stimɪŋ dip ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz tʃɛst, pʌlsɪŋ laɪk ə sɛkən hɑɹt.

She flirted with his prohibition, following him through the town like this. However, she had not shown him her face, and so he let her go. It had probably been a poor move to exile her in the first place, but there was no going back now. He would just have to control his temper in the future. Keep it wrapped in ice, steaming deep inside his chest, pulsing like a second heart.

hi tɝn bæk tə ðə dɑks. pɝhæps ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ɪm tə tʃɛk ɑn ðə fud dɪstʃɹəbjuʃən dɝɛkli. haʊɛvɝ, hi hæd faʊn ðət ðə ɡɹeɪn hæɾ ə dɪstɪŋkli haɪɝ tʃæns ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ tə ðoʊz u niɾəd ɪɾ ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ wɑtʃt. ðɪs wɑz ə pipəl u hæd bɪn wɪθaʊɾ ə kɪŋ fəɹ tu lɔŋ; ðeɪ dɪzɝv tə si ðət sʌmwʌn wɑz ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl.

He turned back to the docks. Perhaps there was no reason for him to check on the food distribution directly. However, he had found that the grain had a distinctly higher chance of getting to those who needed it if everyone knew they were being watched. This was a people who had been without a king for too long; they deserved to see that someone was in control.

əpɑn ɹitʃɪŋ ðə wɔɹf, hi tɝn teɪdeɪʃɝ tə æŋɡəl əlɔŋ ðə bæk ə ðə dɑks, muvɪŋ əɾ ən ənhɝid peɪs. hi ɡlænst ət ði æʃəmən ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm. nf hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ, ɹɛktæŋɡjəlɝ feɪs ən ðə lin bɪld ʌv ə wɔɹiɝ; hid bɪn ə soʊlʒɝ ɪn ðə kwinz ɡɑɹɾ ʌv ændɝ bɪfɔɹ ɹɪzaɪnɪŋ ɪn dɪsɡʌs dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɹeɪn ʌv "lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl." nf hæd faʊn ɪz weɪ tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, ən naʊ wɔɹ boʊθ ðə sɔɹɾ ən dʒɹæɡən.

Upon reaching the wharf, he turned Tai'daishar to angle along the back of the docks, moving at an unhurried pace. He glanced at the Asha'man riding beside him. Naeff had a strong, rectangular face and the lean build of a warrior; he'd been a soldier in the Queen's Guard of Andor before resigning in disgust during the reign of "Lord Gaebril." Naeff had found his way to the Black Tower, and now wore both the Sword and Dragon.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɹænd wəd pɹɑbli hæv tə iðɝ lɛt nf ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ - hi hæd bɪn əmʌŋ ðə fɝst wʌnz bɑndəd - əɹ bɹɪŋ əɹ tə hɪm. hi wɑz loʊθ tə hæv ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ nɪɹbaɪ, ɔlðoʊ nəlɑvɛɹ diməsiɛlɪn, ə ɡɹin, wɑz ɹɛləɾɪvli plɛzən əz ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛnt.

Eventually, Rand would probably have to either let Naeff return to his Aes Sedai - he had been among the first ones bonded - or bring her to him. He was loath to have another Aes Sedai nearby, although Nelavaire Demasiellin, a Green, was relatively pleasant as Aes Sedai went.

"kəntɪnju," ɹænd sɛd tə nf əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd. ði æʃəmən hæd bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ mɛsədʒəz ən miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə sintʃæn wɪð bæʃɪɹ.

"Continue," Rand said to Naeff as they rode. The Asha'man had been running messages and meeting with the Seanchan with Bashere.

"wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd," nf sɛd, "ɪts dʒʌs maɪ ɡʌt filɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəl æksɛp kɑɾɝ fəɹ ðə miɾɪŋ pleɪs. ðeɪ ɔlweɪz ɡɹoʊ dɪfəkəlt wən lɔɹd bæʃɪɹ əɹ aɪ mɛnʃən ɪt, kleɪmɪŋ ðəl əv tə sik fɝðɝ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz fɹəm ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. ðɛɹ toʊnz ɪmplaɪ ðət ði 'ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz' wɪl bi ðət ðə loʊkeɪʃən ɪz ʌnæksɛptəbəl."

"Well, my Lord," Naeff said, "it's just my gut feeling, but I don't think they'll accept Katar for the meeting place. They always grow difficult when Lord Bashere or I mention it, claiming they will have to seek further instructions from the Daughter of the Nine Moons. Their tones imply that the 'instructions' will be that the location is unacceptable."

ɹænd spoʊk sɔfli. "kɑɾɝ ɪz nutʃɹəl ɡɹaʊnd, niðɝ ɪn ɑɹæd dumən nɔɹ dip wɪðɪn sintʃæn lænz."

Rand spoke softly. "Katar is neutral ground, neither in Arad Doman nor deep within Seanchan lands."

"aɪ noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd. wiv tʃɹaɪd. aɪ pɹɑməs ðət wi hæv."

"I know, my Lord. We've tried. I promise that we have."

"vɛɹi wɛl," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪf ðeɪ kəntɪnju tə bi bʊlhɛɾɪd əbaʊt ðɪs, əl tʃuz ənʌðɝ loʊkeɪʃən. ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛm ən seɪ wɪl miɾ ət fɑlm."

"Very well," Rand said. "If they continue to be bullheaded about this, I will choose another location. Return to them and say we will meet at Falme."

fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, flɪn wɪsəl kwaɪətli.

From behind, Flinn whistled quietly.

"maɪ lɔɹd," nf sɛd. "ðæts wɛl wɪðɪn ðə sintʃæn bɔɹɾɝ."

"My Lord," Naeff said. "That's well within the Seanchan border."

"aɪ noʊ," ɹænd sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət flɪn. "bʌɾ ɪts ə . . . sɝɾən hɪstɔɹɪk səɡnɪfɪkəns. wɪl bi seɪf; ðiz sintʃæn ɑɹ baʊn ɹɪdʒɪdli baɪ ðɛɹ ɑnɝ. ðəl nɑɾ ətæk ɪf wi ɝaɪv ʌndɝ ə bænɝ ə tʃɹus."

"I know," Rand said, glancing at Flinn. "But it has a . . . certain historic significance. We will be safe; these Seanchan are bound rigidly by their honor. They will not attack if we arrive under a banner of truce."

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən?" nf æskt kwaɪətli. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ðə weɪ ðeɪ lʊk ət mi, maɪ lɔɹd. ðɛɹz kəntɛmpt ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm. kəntɛmpt ən pɪɾi, əz ɪf ɪm səm lɔs haʊnd, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ skɹæps bɪhaɪn ði ɪn. bɝn mi, bʌɾ ɪt meɪks mi sɪk."

"Are you certain?" Naeff asked quietly. "I don't like the way they look at me, my Lord. There's contempt in their eyes, every one of them. Contempt and pity, as if I'm some lost hound, searching for scraps behind the inn. Burn me, but it makes me sick."

"ðeɪv ɡɑt ðoʊz kɑlɝz ə ðɛɹz hændi, maɪ lɔɹd," flɪn sɛd. "flæɡ ʌv tʃɹus əɹ nɑt, ðəl bi ɪtʃɪŋ tə baɪn əs ɔl."

"They've got those collars of theirs handy, my Lord," Flinn said. "Flag of truce or not, they'll be itching to bind us all."

ɹænd kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, kipɪŋ ðə ɹeɪdʒ ɪnsaɪd, filɪŋ ðə sɔlti si ɛɹ bloʊ əkɹɔs hɪm. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz tə ə skaɪ baʊndəd baɪ dɑɹk klaʊdz. hi wəd nɑt θɪŋk ə ðə kɑlɝ əɾ ɪz nɛk, hɪz hæn stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ mɪn. ðət wɑz ðə pæst.

Rand closed his eyes, keeping the rage inside, feeling the salty sea air blow across him. He opened his eyes to a sky bounded by dark clouds. He would not think of the collar at his neck, his hand strangling Min. That was the past.

hi wɑz hɑɹɾɝ ðən stil. hi kəd nɑt bi bɹoʊkən.

He was harder than steel. He could not be broken.

"wi mʌst əv pis wɪð ðə sintʃæn," hi sɛd. "dɪfɝənsɪz nɑtwɪθstændɪŋ."

"We must have peace with the Seanchan," he said. "Differences notwithstanding."

"dɪfɝənsɪz?" flɪn æskt. "aɪ doʊn ɹaɪtli θɪŋk aɪd kɔl ðəɾ ə dɪfɝəns, maɪ lɔɹd. ðeɪ wɑnə ɛnslɑv ɛvɹi wʌn ʌv ʌs, meɪbi ɛksəkjuɾ ʌs. ðeɪ θɪŋk ɪts ə feɪvɝ tə də iðɝ!"

"Differences?" Flinn asked. "I don't rightly think I'd call that a difference, my Lord. They want to enslave every one of us, maybe execute us. They think it's a favor to do either!"

ɹænd hɛl ðə mænz ɡeɪz. flɪn wɑz nɑt ɹɪbɛljəs; hi wɑz əz lɔɪəl əz ðeɪ keɪm. bʌt stɪl ɹænd meɪɾ ɪm wɪlt ən baʊ hɪz hɛd. dɪsɛnʃən kəd nɑt bi tɑlɝeɪɾəd. dɪsɛnʃən ən laɪz hæd bɹɔɾ ɪm tə ðə kɑlɝ. noʊ mɔɹ.

Rand held the man's gaze. Flinn was not rebellious; he was as loyal as they came. But still Rand made him wilt and bow his head. Dissension could not be tolerated. Dissension and lies had brought him to the collar. No more.

"aɪm sɑɹi, maɪ lɔɹd," flɪn faɪnəli sɛd. "bɝn mi ɪf fɑlm ɪzən ə faɪn tʃɔɪs! jəl əv əm wɑtʃɪŋ ðə skaɪz wɪð fɪɹ, jə wɪl."

"I'm sorry, my Lord," Flinn finally said. "Burn me if Falme isn't a fine choice! You'll have them watching the skies with fear, you will."

"ɡoʊ wɪð ðə mɛsədʒ naʊ, nf," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ wɑn ðɪs sɛɾəld."

"Go with the message now, Naeff," Rand said. "I want this settled."

nf nɑɾəd, tɝnɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ən tʃɹɑɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə kɑləm, ə smɔl ɡɹup ʌv il ɡɑɹdz dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɪm. wʌn kəɾ oʊnli tʃɹævəl fɹəm ə pleɪs wʌn nu wɛl, ən soʊ hi kʊdn sɪmpli liv fɹəm dɑksaɪd. ɹænd kəntɪnjuɾ ɪz ɹaɪd, tʃɹʌbəl baɪ luz θɝɪnz saɪləns. ðə mædmæn hæd bɪn ənjuʒəwəli dɪstən leɪtli. ðət ʃʊɾə plizd ɹænd, bʌɾ ɪt dɪstɝbd ɪm ɪnstɛd. ɪt hæd tə də wɪð ði ənneɪm paʊɝ ðət ɹænd hæd tʌtʃt. hi stɪl ɔfən hɝd ðə mædmæn wipɪŋ, wɪspɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, tɛɹəfaɪd.

Naeff nodded, turning his horse and trotting away from the column, a small group of Aiel guards joining him. One could only Travel from a place one knew well, and so he couldn't simply leave from dockside. Rand continued his ride, troubled by Lews Therin's silence. The madman had been unusually distant lately. That should have pleased Rand, but it disturbed him instead. It had to do with the unnamed power that Rand had touched. He still often heard the madman weeping, whispering to himself, terrified.

"ɹænd?"

"Rand?"

hi tɝnd, nɑt hævɪŋ hɝd nɪneɪivz hɔɹs əpɹoʊtʃ. ʃi wɔɹ ə boʊld ɡɹin dʒɹɛs, mɑɾəst baɪ dəmɑni stændɝdz, bʌt stɪl fɑɹ mɔɹ ɹɪvilɪŋ ðən ʃiɾ ɛvɝ əv kənsɪɾɝd dʊɹɪŋ əɹ deɪz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ʃiz ə ɹaɪt tə tʃeɪnʒ, ɹænd θɔt. wʌɾ ɪz ə lusənɪŋ ə dʒɹɛs kəmpɛɹd tə ðə fæk ðəɾ aɪ hæv ɔɹɾɝd ɛɡzaɪlz ən ɛksəkjuʃənz?

He turned, not having heard Nynaeve's horse approach. She wore a bold green dress, modest by Domani standards, but still far more revealing than she'd ever have considered during her days in the Two Rivers. She has a right to change, Rand thought. What is a loosening of dress compared to the fact that I have ordered exiles and executions?

"wʌt dɪd jə dɪsaɪd?" ʃi æskt.

"What did you decide?" she asked.

"wi wɪl miɾ əm ət fɑlm," hi sɛd.

"We will meet them at Falme," he said.

ʃi mʌɾɝd kwaɪətli.

She muttered quietly.

"wʌt wɑz ðæt?" hi æskt.

"What was that?" he asked.

"oʊ, dʒʌst sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt jə biɪŋ ə wʊl-hɛɾəd ful," ʃi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð dɪfaɪən aɪz.

"Oh, just something about you being a wool-headed fool," she said, looking at him with defiant eyes.

"fɑlm wɪl bi əɡɹiəbəl tə ðɛm," hi sɛd.

"Falme will be agreeable to them," he said.

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd. "ɪt pʊts jə pɝfəkli wɪðɪn ðɛɹ hænz."

"Yes," she said. "It puts you perfectly within their hands."

"aɪ kænɑɾ əfɔɹd tə weɪt, nɪneɪiv," hi sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz ə ɹɪsk wi mʌs teɪk. bʌɾ aɪ daʊt ðəl ətæk."

"I cannot afford to wait, Nynaeve," he said. "This is a risk we must take. But I doubt they will attack."

"dɪd jə daʊɾ ɪt læs taɪm tu?" ʃi æskt. "ðə taɪm wən ðeɪ tʊk jəɹ hænd?"

"Did you doubt it last time too?" she asked. "The time when they took your hand?"

hi ɡlæns daʊn əɾ ɪz stʌmp. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ənlaɪkli tə hæv wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɪð əm ðɪs taɪm."

He glanced down at his stump. "They are unlikely to have one of the Forsaken with them this time."

"ju kən bi ʃʊɹ?"

"You can be sure?"

hi mɛɾ əɹ aɪz, ən ʃi hɛl ðɛm, sʌmθɪŋ fju pipəl kəd sim tə mænədʒ ðiz deɪz.

He met her eyes, and she held them, something few people could seem to manage these days.

faɪnəli, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ kænɑt bi ʃʊɹ."

Finally, he shook his head. "I cannot be sure."

ʃi snɪft ɪn ɹɪspɑns, ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ ðət ʃid wʌn ðəɾ ɑɹɡjəmənt. "wɛl, wɪl dʒʌst əv tə bi ɛkstʃɹə kɛɹfəl. pɝhæps mɛmɹiz ə ðə læs taɪm jə vɪzəɾəd fɑlm wɪl meɪk əm ənkʌmftəɹbəl."

She sniffed in response, indicating that she'd won that argument. "Well, we'll just have to be extra careful. Perhaps memories of the last time you visited Falme will make them uncomfortable."

"aɪ hoʊp soʊ," hi sɛd.

"I hope so," he said.

ʃi mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ɛls tə hɝsɛlf, bʌɾ i dɪdn kætʃ ɪt. nɪneɪiv wəd nɛvɝ meɪk ən aɪdil ɛɛs sədaɪ; ʃi wɑz fɑɹ tu fɹi wɪð əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli hɝ tɛmpɝ. ɹænd dɪd nɑt faɪn ɪɾ ə fɔlt; ət list i ɔlweɪz nu wɛɹ i stʊd wɪð nɪneɪiv. ʃi wɑz tɛɹəbəl ət ɡeɪmz, ən ðət meɪɾ əɹ væljəbəl. hi tʃɹʌstɪd hɝ. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju.

She muttered something else to herself, but he didn't catch it. Nynaeve would never make an ideal Aes Sedai; she was far too free with her emotions, particularly her temper. Rand did not find it a fault; at least he always knew where he stood with Nynaeve. She was terrible at games, and that made her valuable. He trusted her. She was one of the few.

wi də tʃɹʌs hɝ, doʊnt wi? luz θɝɪn æskt. kən wi?

We do trust her, don't we? Lews Therin asked. Can we?

ɹænd dɪdn ænsɝ. hi kəmpliɾəd ɪz ɹivju ʌv ðə dɑks. nɪneɪiv steɪɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd. ʃi sim tə bi ɪn ə dɑɹk mud, ðoʊ ɹænd kʊdn si waɪ. wɪð kædzueɪnz bænɪʃmənt, nɪneɪiv kəd fɪl ðə ɹoʊl əz ɪz pɹaɪmɛɹi ædvaɪzɝ. dɪdn ðət pliz hɝ?

Rand didn't answer. He completed his review of the docks. Nynaeve stayed at his side. She seemed to be in a dark mood, though Rand couldn't see why. With Cadsuane's banishment, Nynaeve could fill the role as his primary advisor. Didn't that please her?

pɝhæps ʃi wɑz wɝiɾ əbaʊt læn. əz ɹænd tɝn ɪz pɹəsɛʃən bæk təwɔɹd ðə sɛntɝ ə taʊn, hi æskt, "hæv jə hɝd fɹəm hɪm?"

Perhaps she was worried about Lan. As Rand turned his procession back toward the center of town, he asked, "Have you heard from him?"

nɪneɪiv ɡlænst ət hɪm, aɪz nɛɹoʊɪŋ. "hu?"

Nynaeve glanced at him, eyes narrowing. "Who?"

"ju noʊ hu," ɹænd sɛd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ pæst ə ɹoʊ ʌv bɹaɪt ɹɛd bænɝz weɪvɪŋ ətɑp ə laɪn ə hoʊmz, itʃ hoʊldɪŋ siənz ə ðə seɪm fæmli.

"You know who," Rand said, riding past a row of bright red banners waving atop a line of homes, each holding scions of the same family.

"hɪz ækʃənz ɑɹ nʌn ə jəɹ kənsɝn," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"His actions are none of your concern," Nynaeve said.

"ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld ɪz maɪ kənsɝn, nɪneɪiv." hi lʊkt ət hɝ. "wʊd jə nɑɾ əɡɹi?"

"The entire world is my concern, Nynaeve." He looked at her. "Would you not agree?"

ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊð, noʊ daʊt tə snæp ət hɪm, bʌt fɔltɝɾ əz ʃi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. laɪt, hi θɔt, siɪŋ ði æpɹɪhɛnʃən ɪn əɹ feɪs. aɪ kən də ɪt tə nɪneɪiv, naʊ. wʌɾ ɪz ɪt ðət ðeɪ si wən ðeɪ lʊk ət mi? ðət lʊk ɪn əɹ aɪz ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪm fɹaɪɾənd ə hɪmsɛlf.

She opened her mouth, no doubt to snap at him, but faltered as she met his eyes. Light, he thought, seeing the apprehension in her face. I can do it to Nynaeve, now. What is it that they see when they look at me? That look in her eyes almost made him frightened of himself.

"læn wɪl bi wɛl," nɪneɪiv sɛd, lʊkɪŋ əweɪ.

"Lan will be well," Nynaeve said, looking away.

"hi hæz ɹɪɾən tə mɔlkiɝ, hæzən hi?"

"He has ridden to Malkier, hasn't he?"

ʃi flʌʃt.

She flushed.

"haʊ lɔŋ?" ɹænd æskt. "hi hæzənt ɡɑɾən tə ðə blaɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, hæz hi?" tɝn lus tə fɑloʊ wʌɾ i sɔ əz boʊθ ɪz duɾi ən dɛstəni, læn wəd ɹaɪd stʃɹeɪt tə mɔlkiɝ əloʊn. ðə kɪŋdəm - hɪz kɪŋdəm - hæd bɪn kənsum baɪ ðə blaɪt dɛkeɪdz əɡoʊ, wən hid bɪn ə beɪb.

"How long?" Rand asked. "He hasn't gotten to the Blight already, has he?" Turned loose to follow what he saw as both his duty and destiny, Lan would ride straight to Malkier alone. The kingdom - his kingdom - had been consumed by the Blight decades ago, when he'd been a babe.

"tu əɹ θɹi mɔɹ mʌnθs," ʃi sɛd. "pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. hi ɹaɪdz tə ʃaɪnɝ tə stæn ət ðə ɡæp, ivən ɪf hiz tə də soʊ əloʊn."

"Two or three more months," she said. "Perhaps a little longer. He rides to Shienar to stand at the Gap, even if he has to do so alone."

"hi siks vɛnʒəns," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. " 'tə əvɛnʒ wʌt kænɑt bi dɪfɛndəd.' "

"He seeks vengeance," Rand said softly. " 'To avenge what cannot be defended.' "

"hi dʌz ɪz duɾi!" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "bʌt . . . aɪ də wɝi əɾ ɪz bɹæʃnəs. hi ɪnsɪstəd ðəɾ aɪ teɪk ɪm tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, soʊ aɪ dɪd, bʌɾ aɪ lɛft ɪm ɪn sɑldɑiə. aɪ wɑntəɾ ɪm əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə ɡæp əz pɑsəbəl. hɪl əv tə kɹɔs səm dɪfəkəl tɝeɪn tə ɡɛt wɛɹ hiz ɡoʊɪŋ."

"He does his duty!" Nynaeve said. "But . . . I do worry at his brashness. He insisted that I take him to the Borderlands, so I did, but I left him in Saldaea. I wanted him as far from the Gap as possible. He'll have to cross some difficult terrain to get where he's going."

ɹænd fɛlt ən aɪsi koʊlnəs əz i kənsɪɾɝd læn ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə ɡæp. tə hɪz dɛθ, ɪsɛnʃəli. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊt ðæt. "aɪ æm sɑɹi, nɪneɪiv," hi sɛd, ðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt fil ɪt. hi hæd tʃɹʌbəl filɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ leɪtli.

Rand felt an icy coldness as he considered Lan riding to the Gap. To his death, essentially. But there was nothing to be done about that. "I am sorry, Nynaeve," he said, though he did not feel it. He had trouble feeling anything lately.

"ju θɪŋk aɪd sɛn ɪm əloʊn?" ʃi snæpt. "wʊl-hɛɾəd, boʊθ ə ju! aɪv sin ðət hɪl əv ɪz oʊn ɑɹmi, ɔlðoʊ hi dʌznt wɑnt wʌn."

"You think I'd send him alone?" she snapped. "Wool-headed, both of you! I've seen that he'll have his own army, although he doesn't want one."

ən ʃi wɑz pɝfəkli keɪpəbəl ʌv ɪt. pɝhæps ʃid sɛnt wɔɹnɪŋ tə ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðə mɔlkɪɹi ɪn lænz neɪm. læn wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ mɪkstʃɝ; hi ɹəfjuz tə ɹeɪz ðə bænɝ ə mɔlkiɝ əɹ kleɪm ɪz pleɪs əz ɪts kɪŋ, fəɹ i fɪɹd liɾɪŋ ðə læst ə hɪz kʌntʃɹimɪn tə ðɛɹ dɛθs. jɛɾ i wəd bi pɝfəkli wɪlɪŋ tə ɹaɪd tə ðət seɪm dɛθ hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə neɪm ʌv ɑnɝ.

And she was perfectly capable of it. Perhaps she'd sent warning to the remnants of the Malkieri in Lan's name. Lan was a strange mixture; he refused to raise the banner of Malkier or claim his place as its king, for he feared leading the last of his countrymen to their deaths. Yet he would be perfectly willing to ride to that same death himself in the name of honor.

ɪz ðət wʌɾ aɪ du? ɹænd θɔt. ɹaɪd tə maɪ dɛθ ɪn ðə neɪm ʌv ɑnɝ? bʌt noʊ, ɪts dɪfɹənt.

Is that what I do? Rand thought. Ride to my death in the name of honor? But no, it's different.

læn əz ə tʃɔɪs. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ pɹɑfəsiz seɪɪŋ ðət læn wəd daɪ, wʌtɛvɝ ðə mænz əsʌmpʃənz əbaʊɾ ɪz oʊn feɪt.

Lan has a choice. There were no prophecies saying that Lan would die, whatever the man's assumptions about his own fate.

"hi kəd juz səm hɛlp ɹəɡɑɹdləs," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ənkʌmftəbli. æskɪŋ fəɹ hɛlp ɔlweɪz meɪɾ əɹ ənkʌmftəɹbəl. "hɪz ɑɹmi wɪl bi smɔl. aɪ daʊt ðəl stæn lɔŋ əɡɛns ðə tʃɹɑləks."

"He could use some help regardless," Nynaeve said uncomfortably. Asking for help always made her uncomfortable. "His army will be small. I doubt they'll stand long against the Trollocs."

"wɪl i ətæk?" ɹænd æskt.

"Will he attack?" Rand asked.

nɪneɪiv hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "hi dɪdn seɪ," ʃi sɛd. "bʌt jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk i wɪl. hi θɪŋks jə ɑɹ weɪstɪŋ taɪm hɪɹ, ɹænd. ɪf i ɝaɪvz ən ɡæðɝz ən ɑɹmi, ən faɪnz tʃɹɑləks ɡæðɝɾ ət tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp . . .

Nynaeve hesitated. "He didn't say," she said. "But yes, I think he will. He thinks you are wasting time here, Rand. If he arrives and gathers an army, and finds Trollocs gathered at Tarwin's Gap . . .

jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk hɪl ətæk."

yes, I think he'll attack."

"ðɛn i dɪzɝvz wʌt hɪl ɡɛt, fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪθaʊt ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs," ɹænd sɛd.

"Then he deserves what he will get, for riding without the rest of us," Rand said.

nɪneɪiv skaʊld ət hɪm. "haʊ kən jə seɪ ðæt?"

Nynaeve scowled at him. "How can you say that?"

"aɪ mʌst," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd sɔfli. "ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz ɪmənənt. pɝhæps maɪ oʊn ətæk ɑn ðə blaɪt wɪl hæpən ət ðə seɪm taɪm əz lænz. pɝhæps nɑt." hi pɔz θɔtfəli. ɪf læn ən wʌtɛvɝ ɑɹmi hi bɹɔɾ ɛnɡeɪdʒd ət ðə ɡæp . . . pɝhæps ðət wəd dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən. ɪf ɹænd dɪdn ətæk ðɛɹ, ɪt wəd θɹoʊ ɔf ðə ʃædoʊ. hi kəd stʃɹaɪk əm wɛɹ ðeɪ dɪdn ɪkspɛkt ɪt waɪl ðɛɹ aɪz wɝ ɑn læn.

"I must," Rand replied softly. "The Last Battle is imminent. Perhaps my own attack on the Blight will happen at the same time as Lan's. Perhaps not." He paused thoughtfully. If Lan and whatever army he brought engaged at the Gap . . . perhaps that would draw attention. If Rand didn't attack there, it would throw off the Shadow. He could strike them where they didn't expect it while their eyes were on Lan.

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd θɔtfəli. "hɪz dɛθ kəd sɝv mi wɛl ɪndid."

"Yes," Rand said thoughtfully. "His death could serve me well indeed."

nɪneɪivz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn fjʊɹi, bʌt ɹænd ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ. ə vɛɹi kwaɪət pleɪs, dip ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm, wɑz stʃɹʌk wɪð wɝi oʊvɝ ɪz fɹɛnd. hi hæd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðət wɝi, saɪləns ɪt. bʌt ðət vɔɪs wɪspɝd tə hɪm.

Nynaeve's eyes widened in fury, but Rand ignored her. A very quiet place, deep inside of him, was struck with worry over his friend. He had to ignore that worry, silence it. But that voice whispered to him.

hi neɪm jə fɹɛnd. də nɑɾ əbændən hɪm. . . .

He named you friend. Do not abandon him. . . .

nɪneɪiv kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ æŋɡɝ, wɪtʃ ɪmpɹɛst ɹænd. "wi wɪl spik ə ðɪs əɡɛn," ʃi sɛd tə hɪm, vɔɪs kɝt. "pɝhæps æftɝ juv hæɾ ə tʃæns tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪɡzækli wʌɾ əbændənɪŋ læn wəd min."

Nynaeve controlled her anger, which impressed Rand. "We will speak of this again," she said to him, voice curt. "Perhaps after you've had a chance to think on exactly what abandoning Lan would mean."

hi laɪk tə θɪŋk ə nɪneɪiv əz ðə seɪm bəlɪdʒɝənt wɪzdəm u hæd bʊliɾ ɪm bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz simd əz ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd tu hɑɹd, əz ɪf ʃi hæd wɝid ðəɾ ʌðɝz wəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ əɹ taɪɾəl kəz ə hɝ juθ. bʌt ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ə lɑt sɪns ðɛn.

He liked to think of Nynaeve as the same belligerent Wisdom who had bullied him back in the Two Rivers. She'd always seemed as if she tried too hard, as if she had worried that others would ignore her title because of her youth. But she had grown a lot since then.

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə mænʃən, wɛɹ fɪfti ʌv bæʃɪɹz soʊlʒɝz stʊd ɡɑɹd bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡeɪts. ðeɪ səluɾəd ɪn junəsən əz ɹænd pæs θɹu ðɛm. hi pæst il kæmpt aʊtsaɪd, dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ət ðə steɪbəlz ən tʃɹænsfɝd ði æksɛs ki fɹəm ɪts lup ɑn ɪz sæɾəl tə ði oʊvɝsaɪz pɑkəɾ ə hɪz koʊt  - mɔɹ ʌv ə paʊtʃ, bʌɾənd ɪndə hɪz koʊt - dɪzaɪn fəɹ ðə stætʃuɛt. ðə hæn hoʊldɪŋ ɪts ɡloʊb əlɔft ɹitʃt aʊɾ ʌv ɪts dɛpθs.

They reached the mansion, where fifty of Bashere's soldiers stood guard before the gates. They saluted in unison as Rand passed through them. He passed Aiel camped outside, dismounted at the stables and transferred the access key from its loop on his saddle to the oversized pocket of his coat  - more of a pouch, buttoned into his coat - designed for the statuette. The hand holding its globe aloft reached out of its depths.

hi wɛn tə hɪz θɹoʊn ɹum. hi kʊdn kɔl ɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ðæt, naʊ ðət ðə kɪŋz θɹoʊn hæd bɪn bɹɔt tə hɪm. ɪt wɑz oʊvɝsaɪzd, wɪð ɡɪldɪŋ ən dʒɛmstoʊnz əfɪks tə ðə wʊɾ ət ði ɑɹmz ən tə ðə bæk, əbʌv ðə hɛd. ðeɪ pɹoʊtʃɹuɾəd laɪk bʌɾɪŋ aɪz, ɡɪvɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn ən ɔɹneɪt ɹɪtʃnəs ðət ɹænd dɪslaɪkt. ɪt hædn bɪn ɪn ðə pæləs. wʌn ə ðə loʊkəl mɝtʃəns hæd bɪn "pɹətɛktɪŋ" ɪt fɹəm ðə ɹaɪəts. pɝhæps i hæd kənsɪɾɝd sizɪŋ ðə siɾ ɪn ə mɔɹ fɪɡjɝəɾɪv sɛns əz wɛl.

He went to his throne room. He couldn't call it anything other than that, now that the King's throne had been brought to him. It was oversized, with gilding and gemstones affixed to the wood at the arms and to the back, above the head. They protruded like budding eyes, giving the throne an ornate richness that Rand disliked. It hadn't been in the palace. One of the local merchants had been "protecting" it from the riots. Perhaps he had considered seizing the seat in a more figurative sense as well.

ɹænd sæɾ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn, dɪspaɪɾ ɪts ɡɔɾinəs, ʃɪftɪŋ soʊ ðət ði æksɛs ki ɪn ɪz pɑkət dɪdn dʒæb ɪm ɪn ðə saɪd. ðə paʊɝfəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɝn sɝɾən wʌt tə θɪŋk ə hɪm, ən i pɹəfɝɾ ɪt ðət weɪ. hi dɪdnt neɪm hɪmsɛlf kɪŋ, jɛɾ ɪz ɑɹmiz sɪkjʊɹd ðə kæpəɾəl. hi spoʊk ə ɹɪstɔɹɪŋ ælsələmz pleɪs tə hɪm, jɛt sæɾ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn əz ɪf i hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə ɪt. hi hæd nɑt muvd ɪndə ðə pæləs. hi wɑntəɾ əm tə wʌndɝ.

Rand sat on the throne, despite its gaudiness, shifting so that the access key in his pocket didn't jab him in the side. The powerful in the city weren't certain what to think of him, and he preferred it that way. He didn't name himself king, yet his armies secured the capital. He spoke of restoring Alsalam's place to him, yet sat on the throne as if he had a right to it. He had not moved into the palace. He wanted them to wonder.

ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi hædn meɪɾ ə dɪsɪʒən. ə lɑt wəd dɪpɛn ɑn ðɪs deɪz ɹɪpɔɹts. hi nɑɾəd tə ɹəɑɹk əz i ɛntɝd; ðə mʌskjəlɝ ilmən ɹɪtɝn ðə dʒɛstʃɝ. ðən ɹænd stɛp daʊn fɹəm ðə θɹoʊn ən i ən ɹəɑɹk sæt daʊn ɑn ðə sɝkjəlɝ ɹʌɡ ʌv spaɪɹəlɪŋ kʌlɝz wɪtʃ leɪ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡɹin-kɑɹpəɾɪd deɪz. ðə fɝs taɪm ðeɪd dʌn ðɪs, ɪt hæd kɑzd ə kwaɪət stɝ əmʌŋ ðə dəmɑni ətɛndəns ən fʌŋkʃənɛɹiz ə ɹændz ɡɹoʊɪŋ kɔɹt.

In truth, he hadn't made a decision. A lot would depend on this day's reports. He nodded to Rhuarc as he entered; the muscular Aielman returned the gesture. Then Rand stepped down from the throne and he and Rhuarc sat down on the circular rug of spiraling colors which lay on the floor in front of the green-carpeted dais. The first time they'd done this, it had caused a quiet stir among the Domani attendants and functionaries of Rand's growing court.

"wi hæv loʊkeɪɾəd ən teɪkən ənʌðɝ ə ðɛm, ɹænd ælθɹ," ɹəɑɹk sɛd. "æləmɪnʒɹə kʌɾɝən wɑz haɪɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ kʌzənz lænz nɪɹ ðə nɔɹðɝn bɔɹɾɝ; wʌt wi lɝn ɑn əɹ ɪsteɪt lɛɾ əs dɝɛkli tə hɝ."

"We have located and taken another of them, Rand al'Thor," Rhuarc said. "Alamindra Cutren was hiding on her cousin's lands near the northern border; what we learned on her estate led us directly to her."

ðət meɪd fɔɹ mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl ɪn ɪz kʌstəɾi. "wʌɾ ə miʃən dubɛɹis? jə sɛd jə maɪɾ əv əɹ əz wɛl."

That made four members of the merchant council in his custody. "What of Meashan Dubaris? You said you might have her as well."

"dɛd," ɹəɑɹk sɛd. "baɪ ðə hænz ʌv ə mɑb ə wik ɡɔn."

"Dead," Rhuarc said. "By the hands of a mob a week gone."

"ju ɑɹ sɝɾən ə ðɪs? ɪt kəd bi ə laɪ tə sɛt jə ɔf əɹ tʃɹæk."

"You are certain of this? It could be a lie to set you off her track."

"aɪ hæv nɑt sin ðə bɑɾi maɪsɛlf," ɹəɑɹk sɛd, "bʌt mɛn aɪ tʃɹʌs hæv, ən ðeɪ seɪ ɪt mætʃəz əɹ dɪskɹɪpʃən. aɪm ɹizənəbli əʃʊɹd ðət ðə tʃɹeɪl wɑz dʒɛnjəwən."

"I have not seen the body myself," Rhuarc said, "but men I trust have, and they say it matches her description. I am reasonably assured that the trail was genuine."

fɔɹ kæptʃɝd, ən tu dɛd, ðɛn. ðət lɛft fɔɹ mɔɹ tə loʊkeɪt bɪfɔɹ i hæɾ ɪnʌf mɛmbɝz tə ɔɹɾɝ ə nu voʊt fəɹ kɪŋ. ɪt wəd nɑt bi ðə moʊst ɛθəkəl kaʊnsəl ɪlɛkʃən ɪn dəmɑni hɪstɝi; waɪ dɪɾ i bɑðɝ? hi kəɾ əpɔɪn ə kɪŋ, əɹ neɪm hɪmsɛlf tə ðə θɹoʊn. waɪ dɪɾ i kɛɹ wʌt ðə dəmɑni θɔt pɹɑpɝ?

Four captured, and two dead, then. That left four more to locate before he had enough members to order a new vote for king. It would not be the most ethical council election in Domani history; why did he bother? He could appoint a king, or name himself to the throne. Why did he care what the Domani thought proper?

ɹəɑɹk wɑtʃt hɪm; ði il tʃifs aɪz wɝ θɔtfəl. hi laɪkli wʌndɝd ðə seɪm θɪŋz.

Rhuarc watched him; the Aiel chief's eyes were thoughtful. He likely wondered the same things.

"kip sɝtʃɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ də nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə teɪk ɑɹæd dumən fəɹ maɪsɛlf; wɪl faɪn ðə ɹaɪtfəl kɪŋ əɹ wɪl si ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns əsɛmbəl soʊ ðət ðeɪ kən tʃuz ə nu wʌn. əl nɑt kɛɹ u ɪɾ ɪz, soʊ lɔŋ əz hiz nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"Keep searching," Rand said. "I do not intend to take Arad Doman for myself; we will find the rightful king or we will see the Council of Merchants assembled so that they can choose a new one. I will not care who it is, so long as he is not a Darkfriend."

"æz jə seɪ, kɑɹəkɑɹn," ɹəɑɹk sɛd, muvɪŋ tə ɹaɪz.

"As you say, Car'a'carn," Rhuarc said, moving to rise.

"ɔɹɾɝ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ɹəɑɹk," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ doʊn əv taɪm tə sɪkjʊɹ ðɪs kɪŋdəm maɪsɛlf. wi doʊn əv lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl." hi ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv, hu hæd dʒɔɪn sɛvɹəl meɪɾənz ət ðə bæk ə ðə smɔl ɹum. "aɪ wɑn fɔɹ mɔɹ mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl ɪn əɹ pəzɛʃən baɪ ði ɛn ə ðə mʌnθ."

"Order is important, Rhuarc," Rand said. "I don't have time to secure this kingdom myself. We don't have long before the Last Battle." He glanced at Nynaeve, who had joined several Maidens at the back of the small room. "I want four more members of the merchant council in our possession by the end of the month."

"ju sɛɾ ə dɪmændɪŋ peɪs, ɹænd ælθɹ," ɹəɑɹk sɛd.

"You set a demanding pace, Rand al'Thor," Rhuarc said.

ɹænd stʊɾ ʌp. "dʒʌs faɪn mi ðoʊz mɝtʃəns. ðiz pipəl dɪzɝv liɾɝz."

Rand stood up. "Just find me those merchants. These people deserve leaders."

"æn ðə kɪŋ?"

"And the king?"

ɹænd ɡlæns tə ðə saɪd, tə wɛɹ maɪləsɹ tʃædmɑɝ stʊd, kɛɹfəli wɑtʃt baɪ il ɡɑɹdz.

Rand glanced to the side, to where Milisair Chadmar stood, carefully watched by Aiel guards.

ʃi simd . . . hæɡɝd. hɝ wʌns-ləɡʒɝiəs ɹeɪvən hɛɹ hæd bɪn pʊld ʌp ɪndə ə bʌn, ɑbviəsli kəz ɪt wɑz iziɝ tə kɛɹ fəɹ ðət weɪ. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz stɪl ɹɪtʃ, bʌt naʊ ɹɪŋkəld, əz ɪf ʃid bɪn wɛɹɪŋ ɪt fəɹ tu lɔŋ. hɝ aɪz wɝ ɹɛd. ʃi wɑz stɪl bjuɾəfəl, bʌt mʌtʃ ɪn ðə weɪ ðəɾ ə peɪntɪŋ wəd stɪl bi bjuɾəfəl ɪf ɪt wɝ kɹʌmpəld ʌp, ðən smuðd aʊɾ ɑn ə teɪbəl.

She seemed . . . haggard. Her once-luxurious raven hair had been pulled up into a bun, obviously because it was easier to care for that way. Her dress was still rich, but now wrinkled, as if she'd been wearing it for too long. Her eyes were red. She was still beautiful, but much in the way that a painting would still be beautiful if it were crumpled up, then smoothed out on a table.

"meɪ jə faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd, ɹəɑɹk," ɹænd sɛɾ ɪn dɪsmɪsəl.

"May you find water and shade, Rhuarc," Rand said in dismissal.

"meɪ jə faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd, ɹænd ælθɹ." ðə tɔl il wɪθdʒɹu, səm ə hɪz spɪɹz fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm. ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən stɛpt ʌp tə ðə ɡɔɾi θɹoʊn ən sæt. ɹəɑɹk i tʃɹiɾəd wɪð ðə ɹɪspɛkt i dɪzɝvd. ði ʌðɝz . . . wɛl, ðeɪ wəd ɡɛt ðə ɹɪspɛk ðeɪ dɪzɝvd əz wɛl.

"May you find water and shade, Rand al'Thor." The tall Aiel withdrew, some of his spears following him. Rand took a deep breath, then stepped up to the gaudy throne and sat. Rhuarc he treated with the respect he deserved. The others . . . well, they would get the respect they deserved as well.

hi lin fɔɹwɝd, moʊʃənɪŋ maɪləsɹ tə əpɹoʊtʃ. wʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz nʌdʒd əɹ ɪn ðə bæk, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ fɔɹwɝd. ðə wʊmən lʊk fɑɹ mɔɹ æpɹɪhɛnsɪv ðən ʃi hæd ðə læs taɪm ʃi hæd kʌm bɪfɔɹ ɹænd.

He leaned forward, motioning Milisair to approach. One of the Maidens nudged her in the back, forcing her forward. The woman looked far more apprehensive than she had the last time she had come before Rand.

"wɛl?" hi æsk hɝ.

"Well?" he asked her.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən . . ." ʃi bɪɡæn, ɡlænsɪŋ ɝaʊnd, əz ɪf sikɪŋ eɪd fɹəm ðə dəmɑni stuɝdz ən ətɛndəns u stʊd ðɛɹ. ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ; ivən ðə fɑp lɔɹd ɹæmʃələn lʊk ði ʌðɝ weɪ.

"My Lord Dragon . . ." she began, glancing around, as if seeking aid from the Domani stewards and attendants who stood there. They ignored her; even the fop Lord Ramshalan looked the other way.

"spik, wʊmən," ɹænd dɪmændəd.

"Speak, woman," Rand demanded.

"ðə mɛsənʒɝ jə æskt æftɝ," ʃi sɛd. "hi ɪz dɛd."

"The messenger you asked after," she said. "He is dead."

ɹænd tʊk ɪn ə dip bɹɛθ. "æn haʊ dɪd ðɪs hæpən?"

Rand took in a deep breath. "And how did this happen?"

"ðə mɛn aɪ əsaɪn tə wɑtʃ æftɝ hɪm," ʃi sɛd kwɪkli, "aɪ hædn ɹilaɪz haʊ pʊɹli ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹiɾɪŋ ðə mɛsənʒɝ! waɪ, ðeɪ hædnt ɡɪvən ɪm wɔɾɝ fəɹ deɪz, ən ðə fivɝz stʃɹʌk. . . ."

"The men I assigned to watch after him," she said quickly, "I hadn't realized how poorly they were treating the messenger! Why, they hadn't given him water for days, and the fevers struck. . . ."

"ɪn ʌðɝ wɝdz," ɹænd sɛd, "ju feɪl tə ɪkstʃɹækt ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fɹəm hɪm, soʊ jə lɛft ɪm ɪn ə dʌnʒən tə ɹɑt, oʊnli ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wɛɹ i wɑz wən aɪ dɪmændəɾ i bi pɹədust."

"In other words," Rand said, "you failed to extract information from him, so you left him in a dungeon to rot, only remembering where he was when I demanded he be produced."

"kɑɹəkɑɹn," wʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz - ə vɛɹi jʌŋ wʊmən neɪm dʒɑlɑni - sɛd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd.

"Car'a'carn," one of the Maidens - a very young woman named Jalani - said, stepping forward.

"wi faʊn ðɪs wʌn pækɪŋ əɹ θɪŋz, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ plænɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp ðə sɪɾi."

"We found this one packing her things, as if she were planning to escape the city."

maɪləsɹ peɪl vɪzəbli. "lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ʃi sɛd. "ə moʊmən ʌv wiknəs! aɪ - "

Milisair paled visibly. "Lord Dragon," she said. "A moment of weakness! I - "

ɹænd weɪv fəɹ saɪləns. "wʌɾ æm aɪ tə də wɪð jə naʊ?"

Rand waved for silence. "What am I to do with you now?"

"ʃi ʃəd bi ɛksəkjuɾəd, maɪ lɔɹd!" ɹæmʃələn sɛd, stɛpɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ iɡɝli.

"She should be executed, my Lord!" Ramshalan said, stepping forward eagerly.

ɹænd lʊkt ʌp wɪð ə fɹaʊn. hi hædn bɪn æskɪŋ fəɹ ə ɹɪspɑns. læŋki, wɪð wʌn ə ðə θɪn blæk dəmɑni mʌstæʃɪz, ɹæmʃələn hæɾ ə pɹɑmənənt noʊz ðət maɪɾ əv ɪndəkeɪɾəd səm sɑldəiən fɔɹbɛɹ. hi wɔɹ ən aʊtʃɹeɪdʒəs koʊɾ ə blu, ɔɹənʒ ən jɛloʊ, wɪð ɹʌfəld waɪt kʌfs pikɪŋ aʊɾ ʌndɝniθ. əpɛɹənli, sətʃ θɪŋz pæs fəɹ fæʃənəbəl əmʌŋ səm sɛɡməns ə ðə dəmɑni ʌpɝ kɹʌst. hɪz ɪɹɪŋz bɔɹ ðə mɑɹk ə hɪz haʊs, ən i hæɾ ə blæk bjuɾi mɑɹk ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə bɝɾ ɪn flaɪɾ əfɪks tə hɪz tʃɛk.

Rand looked up with a frown. He hadn't been asking for a response. Lanky, with one of the thin black Domani mustaches, Ramshalan had a prominent nose that might have indicated some Saldaean forebear. He wore an outrageous coat of blue, orange and yellow, with ruffled white cuffs peeking out underneath. Apparently, such things passed for fashionable among some segments of the Domani upper crust. His earrings bore the mark of his house, and he had a black beauty mark in the shape of a bird in flight affixed to his check.

ɹænd hæd noʊn mɛni laɪk hɪm, kɔɹɾiɝz wɪð tu fju bɹeɪnz bʌt tu mɛni fæmli kənɛkʃənz.

Rand had known many like him, courtiers with too few brains but too many family connections.

noʊbəl laɪf sim tə bɹid ðɛm, mʌtʃ əz ðə tu ɹɪvɝz bɹɛd ʃip. ɹæmʃələn wɑz pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ənɔɪɪŋ kəz ə hɪz neɪzəl vɔɪs ən iɡɝ wɪlɪŋnəs tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ʌðɝz ɪn ɪz dɪzaɪɝ tə kʌɹi feɪvɝ wɪð ɹænd.

Noble life seemed to breed them, much as the Two Rivers bred sheep. Ramshalan was particularly annoying because of his nasal voice and eager willingness to betray others in his desire to curry favor with Rand.

stɪl, mɛn laɪk ɪm hæd ðɛɹ juzɪz. əkeɪʒənəli. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk, maɪləsɹ?" ɹænd sɛd mjuzɪŋli. "ʃʊɾ aɪ hæv jə ɛksəkjuɾəd fəɹ tʃɹizən, əz ðɪs mæn sədʒɛsts?"

Still, men like him had their uses. Occasionally. "What do you think, Milisair?" Rand said musingly. "Should I have you executed for treason, as this man suggests?"

ʃi dɪd nɑt wip, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɑbviəsli tɛɹəfaɪd, hɝ hænz ʃeɪkɪŋ əz ʃi hɛld əm aʊt, hɝ aɪz waɪd, ənblɪŋkɪŋ.

She did not weep, but she was obviously terrified, her hands shaking as she held them out, her eyes wide, unblinking.

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛd faɪnəli. "aɪ nid jə tə hɛlp tʃuz ə nu kɪŋ. wʌt ɡʊd wəɾ ɪt də tə sɝtʃ ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd fəɹ jəɹ kɑliɡz ɪf aɪ bɪɡæn tə ɛksəkjut ðə kaʊnsəl mɛmbɝz aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi faʊnd?"

"No," Rand said finally. "I need you to help choose a new king. What good would it do to search the countryside for your colleagues if I began to execute the Council members I've already found?"

ʃi lɛɾ aʊt ðə bɹɛθ ʃi hæd bɪn hoʊldɪŋ, ən tɛnʃən lɛft əɹ ʃoʊldɝz "lɑk əɹ ɪn ðə seɪm dʌnʒən wɛɹ ʃi ɪmpɹɪzən ðə kɪŋz mɛsənʒɝ," ɹænd sɛd tə ðə meɪɾənz. "meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi dʌzn sʌfɝ ðə seɪm feɪt - ət list, nɑɾ əntɪl æftɝ aɪm fɪnɪʃt wɪð hɝ."

She let out the breath she had been holding, and tension left her shoulders "Lock her in the same dungeon where she imprisoned the King's messenger," Rand said to the Maidens. "Make sure she doesn't suffer the same fate - at least, not until after I'm finished with her."

maɪləsɹ kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn dɪspɛɹ. il meɪɾənz pʊld əɹ fɹəm ðə ɹum skɹimɪŋ, bʌt ɹænd hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pʊɾ əɹ fɹəm ɪz hɛd. ɹæmʃələn wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ wɪð sæɾəsfækʃən; əpɛɹənli, ʃiɾ ɪnsʌltɪɾ ɪm sɛvɹəl taɪmz ɪn pʌblɪk. ðət wɑz wʌn pɔɪn ɪn əɹ feɪvɝ.

Milisair cried out in despair. Aiel Maidens pulled her from the room screaming, but Rand had already put her from his head. Ramshalan watched her go with satisfaction; apparently, she'd insulted him several times in public. That was one point in her favor.

"ði ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl," ɹænd sɛd tə ðə fʌŋkʃənɛɹiz. "hæv ɛni ʌv əm hæd kɑntækt wɪð ðə kɪŋ?"

"The other members of the merchant council," Rand said to the functionaries. "Have any of them had contact with the King?"

"nʌn mɔɹ ɹisənli ðən fɔɹ əɹ faɪv mʌnθs əɡoʊ, maɪ lɔɹd," sɛd wʌn ə ðɛm, ə stʌmpi, lɑɹdʒ- bɛlid dəmɑni mæn neɪm nɔɹəlɑdim. "ðoʊ wi doʊnt noʊ əbaʊɾ æləmɪnʒɹə, əz ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ɹisənli . . . dɪskʌvɝd."

"None more recently than four or five months ago, my Lord," said one of them, a stumpy, large- bellied Domani man named Noreladim. "Though we don't know about Alamindra, as she was just recently . . . discovered."

pɝhæps ʃi wəɾ əv nuz, ðoʊ hi kʊdn si hɝ hævɪŋ ə bɛɾɝ lɛd ðən ə mɛsənʒɝ u kleɪm tə hæv kʌm fɹəm ælsələm hɪmsɛlf. bɝn ðət wʊmən fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ ɪm daɪ!

Perhaps she would have news, though he couldn't see her having a better lead than a messenger who claimed to have come from Alsalam himself. Burn that woman for letting him die!

ɪf ɡɹeɪndəl sɛn ðə mɛsənʒɝ, luz θɝɪn sɛd sʌɾənli, aɪɾ əv nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə bɹeɪk hɪm. ʃiz tu ɡʊd wɪð kəmpʌlʃən. kɹæfti, soʊ kɹæfti.

If Graendal sent the messenger, Lews Therin said suddenly, I'd have never been able to break him. She's too good with Compulsion. Crafty, so crafty.

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd pɔɪnt. ɪf ðə mɛsənʒɝ hæd bɪn sʌbʒɪkt tə ɡɹeɪndəlz kəmpʌlʃən, ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn lɪɾəl tʃæns ə hɪm biɪŋ eɪbəl tə bɪtʃɹeɪ hɝ loʊkeɪʃən. nɑɾ ənlɛs ðə wɛb ə kəmpʌlʃən hæd bɪn lɪftəd, wɪtʃ wʊɾə ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə hilɪŋ bɪɑn ɹændz skɪl. ɡɹeɪndəl hæɾ ɔlweɪz kʌvɝɾ əɹ tʃɹæks wɛl.

Rand hesitated. It was a good point. If the messenger had been subject to Graendal's Compulsion, there would have been little chance of him being able to betray her location. Not unless the web of Compulsion had been lifted, which would have required a Healing beyond Rand's skill. Graendal had always covered her tracks well.

bʌɾ i wɑznt ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi. ɪf i kəd faɪn ə mɛsənʒɝ ən kəmpʌlʃən wɑz ðɛɹ, hiɾ əv ɪnʌf. "aɪ nid tə spik wɪð ɛniwʌn ɛls u kleɪmz tə hæv ə mɛsədʒ fɹəm ðə kɪŋ," hi sɛd. "ʌðɝz ɪn ðə sɪɾi hu maɪɾ əv hæd kɑntækt."

But he wasn't sure she was in the country. If he could find a messenger and Compulsion was there, he'd have enough. "I need to speak with anyone else who claims to have a message from the King," he said. "Others in the city who might have had contact."

"ðeɪ wɪl bi faʊnd, lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," sɛd ðə pɹɪm ɹæmʃələn.

"They will be found, Lord Dragon," said the prim Ramshalan.

ɹænd nɑɾəd æbsənli. ɪf nf sɛɾ ʌp ðə miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə sintʃæn əz hoʊpt, ðən ɹænd kəd liv ɑɹæd dumən sun æftɝ. hi hoʊp tə liv əm wɪð ə kɪŋ, hoʊp tə faɪn ən kɪl ɡɹeɪndəl.

Rand nodded absently. If Naeff set up the meeting with the Seanchan as hoped, then Rand could leave Arad Doman soon after. He hoped to leave them with a king, hoped to find and kill Graendal.

bʌɾ i wəd sɛɾəl fəɹ pis wɪð ðə sintʃæn ən fud fəɹ ðiz pipəl. hi kəd nɑt sɑlv ɛvɹiwʌnz pɹɑbləmz. hi kəd dʒʌs fɔɹs əm ɪndə əbeɪəns lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə daɪ ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

But he would settle for peace with the Seanchan and food for these people. He could not solve everyone's problems. He could just force them into abeyance long enough for him to die at Shayol Ghul.

ən ðɛɹbaɪ liv ðə wɝl tə bɹeɪk əɡɛn wʌns i wɑz ɡɔn. hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi weɪstəd tu mʌtʃ taɪm wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt θɪŋz i kəd nɑt fɪks.

And thereby leave the world to break again once he was gone. He gritted his teeth. He had already wasted too much time worrying about things he could not fix.

ɪz ðət waɪ aɪ ɹɪzɪs neɪmɪŋ ə dəmɑni kɪŋ? hi θɔt. wʌns aɪ daɪ, ðət mæn wəd luz ɪz əθɔɹəɾi, ən ɑɹæd dumən wəd bi bæk wɛɹ ɪt bɪɡæn. ɪf aɪ doʊn liv ə kɪŋ u hæz ðə səpɔɹɾ ə ðə mɝtʃəns, ðən aɪm ɪsɛnʃəli ɔfɝɪŋ ðə kɪŋdəm ʌp tə ðə sintʃæn ðə moʊmən aɪ daɪ.

Is that why I resist naming a Domani king? he thought. Once I die, that man would lose his authority, and Arad Doman would be back where it began. If I don't leave a king who has the support of the merchants, then I'm essentially offering the kingdom up to the Seanchan the moment I die.

soʊ mɛni θɪŋz tə bæləns. soʊ mɛni pɹɑbləmz. hi kʊdn fɪks əm ɔl. hi kʊdnt.

So many things to balance. So many problems. He couldn't fix them all. He couldn't.

"aɪ doʊn əpɹuv ə ðɪs, ɹænd," nɪneɪiv sɛd, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ, ɑɹmz foʊldəd. "ænd wɝ nɑt dʌn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt læn, iðɝ."

"I don't approve of this, Rand," Nynaeve said, standing beside the door, arms folded. "And we're not done talking about Lan, either."

ɹænd weɪvd ə dɪsmɪsɪv hænd.

Rand waved a dismissive hand.

"hiz jəɹ fɹɛnd, ɹænd," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "laɪt! ən wʌɾ ə pɛɹɪn ən mæt? dʒju noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ? wʌɾ əz hæpən tə ðɛm?"

"He's your friend, Rand," Nynaeve said. "Light! And what of Perrin and Mat? Do you know where they are? What has happened to them?"

ðə kʌlɝz swɝl bɪfɔɹ ɪz aɪz, ɹɪvilɪŋ ən ɪmədʒ ə pɛɹɪn stændɪŋ baɪ ə tɛnt wɪð ɡɑləd.

The colors swirled before his eyes, revealing an image of Perrin standing by a tent with Galad.

waɪ wɑz pɛɹɪn wɪð ɡɑləɾ ʌv ɔl pipəl? ən wən hæɾ ɪleɪnz hæf-bɹʌðɝ dʒɔɪn ðə waɪtkloʊks? ðə kʌlɝz tʃeɪnʒd tə mæt, ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə stʃɹits ʌv ə fəmɪljɝ sɪɾi. keɪɛmlɪn? tɑm wɑz ðɛɹ, wɪð hɪm.

Why was Perrin with Galad of all people? And when had Elayne's half-brother joined the Whitecloaks? The colors changed to Mat, riding through the streets of a familiar city. Caemlyn? Thom was there, with him.

ɹænd fɹaʊn tə hɪmsɛlf. hi kəd fil ə pʊl fɹəm pɛɹɪn ən mæt, boʊθ dɪstənt. ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ tɑvɝən nætʃɝz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ ðɛm təɡɛðɝ. ðeɪ boʊθ niɾəd tə bi wɪð ɪm fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl.

Rand frowned to himself. He could feel a pull from Perrin and Mat, both distant. It was their ta'veren natures, trying to draw them together. They both needed to be with him for the Last Battle.

"ɹænd?" nɪneɪiv æskt. "ɑɹən jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɹɪspɑnd?"

"Rand?" Nynaeve asked. "Aren't you going to respond?"

"əbaʊt pɛɹɪn ən mæt?" ɹænd æskt. "ðeɪ lɪv."

"About Perrin and Mat?" Rand asked. "They live."

"haʊ dʒju noʊ?"

"How do you know?"

"aɪ sɪmpli du." hi saɪd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "æn ðeɪ hæd bɛɾɝ ɹɪmeɪn əlaɪv. əl əv niɾ ə ðɛm boʊθ bɪfɔɹ ðɪs ɪz oʊvɝ."

"I simply do." He sighed, shaking his head. "And they had better remain alive. I'll have need of them both before this is over."

"ɹænd!" ʃi sɛd. "ðeɪɹ jəɹ fɹɛnz!"

"Rand!" she said. "They're your friends!"

"ðeɪɹ θɹɛdz ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, nɪneɪiv," hi sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. "aɪ bɛɹli noʊ ðɛm ɛnimɔɹ, ən aɪ səspɛk ðeɪ wəd seɪ ðə seɪm θɪŋ ə mi."
