"They're threads in the Pattern, Nynaeve," he said, rising. "I barely know them anymore, and I suspect they would say the same thing of me."

"doʊn jə kɛɹ əbaʊt ðɛm?"

"Don't you care about them?"

"kɛɹ?" ɹænd wɔk daʊn ðə stɛps ə ðə ɹeɪz plætfɔɹm ðət hɛld ɪz θɹoʊn. "wʌɾ aɪ kɛɹ əbaʊɾ ɪz ðə læs bæɾəl. wʌɾ aɪ kɛɹ əbaʊɾ ɪz meɪkɪŋ pis wɪð ðə laɪt-kɝst sintʃæn soʊ ðəɾ aɪ kən stɑp bɑðɝɪŋ wɪð ðɛɹ skwɑbəl ən ɡɛt tə ðə ɹil bæɾəl. bɪsaɪd ðoʊz kɛɹz, ə pɛɹ ə bɔɪz fɹəm maɪ lɪɾəl vɪlədʒ ɑɹ minɪŋləs."

"Care?" Rand walked down the steps of the raised platform that held his throne. "What I care about is the Last Battle. What I care about is making peace with the Light-cursed Seanchan so that I can stop bothering with their squabble and get to the real battle. Beside those cares, a pair of boys from my little village are meaningless."

hi lʊkt ət hɝ, tʃælənʒɪŋ. ɹæmʃələn ən ði ʌðɝ ətɛndəns bækt əweɪ kwaɪətli, nɑt wɑntɪŋ tə bi kɑt bɪtwin ɪz ɡeɪz ən nɪneɪiv.

He looked at her, challenging. Ramshalan and the other attendants backed away quietly, not wanting to be caught between his gaze and Nynaeve.

ʃi wɑz saɪlənt, ɔlðoʊ hɝ feɪs tʊk ɑn ə pɹoʊfaʊn sædnəs. "oʊ, ɹænd," ʃi faɪnəli sɛd. "ju kænt ɡoʊ ɑn laɪk ðɪs. ðɪs hɑɹdnəs wɪðɪn ju, ɪɾəl bɹeɪk ju."

She was silent, although her face took on a profound sadness. "Oh, Rand," she finally said. "You can't go on like this. This hardness within you, it will break you."

"aɪ də wʌɾ aɪ mʌst," hi sɛd, æŋɡɝ kɹipɪŋ ɪndə hɪm. wəɾ i nɛvɝ hɪɹ ði ɛn ə kəmpleɪns əbaʊɾ ɪz tʃɔɪsəz?

"I do what I must," he said, anger creeping into him. Would he never hear the end of complaints about his choices?

"ðɪs ɪzənt wʌt jə mʌs du, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd. "jɔɹ gɑnə dɪstʃɹɔɪ jɝsɛlf. jəl - "

"This isn't what you must do, Rand," she said. "You're going to destroy yourself. You'll - "

ɹændz æŋɡɝ sɝdʒd. hi spʌn, pɔɪntɪŋ ət hɝ. "wʊd jə ɛn ʌp ɛɡzaɪld laɪk kædzueɪn, nɪneɪiv?" hi bɛloʊd. "aɪ wɪl nɑt bi pleɪd wɪð! aɪm dʌn wɪð ðæt. ɡɪv ædvaɪs wən ɪts æsk fɔɹ, ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taɪm də nɑt peɪtʃɹənaɪz mi!"

Rand's anger surged. He spun, pointing at her. "Would you end up exiled like Cadsuane, Nynaeve?" he bellowed. "I will not be played with! I am done with that. Give advice when it is asked for, and the rest of the time do not patronize me!"

ʃi ɹikɔɪld, ən ɹænd ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, fɔɹsɪŋ ði æŋɡɝ bæk daʊn. hi loʊɝɾ ɪz hænd, bʌt ɹilaɪzd ɪt hæd bɪɡʌn tə ɹitʃ ɹiflɛksɪvli fəɹ ði æksɛs ki ɪn ðə pɑkəɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd. nɪneɪivz aɪz fɪkst ɑn ɪt, oʊpənɪŋ waɪd, ən i sloʊli fɔɹst ɪz hæn əweɪ fɹəm ðə stætʃuɛt.

She recoiled, and Rand gritted his teeth, forcing the anger back down. He lowered his hand, but realized it had begun to reach reflexively for the access key in the pocket at his side. Nynaeve's eyes fixed on it, opening wide, and he slowly forced his hand away from the statuette.

ði ɪksploʊʒən sɝpɹaɪz hɪm. hi hæd θɔɾ ɪz tɛmpɝ kəntʃɹoʊld. hi fɔɹst ɪt daʊn, ən hæɾ ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli dɪfəkəl taɪm ʌv ɪt. hi tɝn ən stɔk fɹəm ðə ɹum, θɹoʊɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, hɪz meɪɾənz fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm. "aɪ wɪl əv noʊ mɔɹ ɑɾiənsəz tədeɪ," hi toʊl ði ətɛndəns u tʃɹaɪd tə fɑloʊ hɪm. "ɡoʊ ən də əz aɪ hæv toʊl ju! aɪ nid ði ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl. ɡoʊ!"

The explosion surprised him. He had thought his temper controlled. He forced it down, and had a surprisingly difficult time of it. He turned and stalked from the room, throwing open the door, his Maidens following him. "I will have no more audiences today," he told the attendants who tried to follow him. "Go and do as I have told you! I need the other members of the merchant council. Go!"

ðeɪ skæɾɝd. oʊnli ði il ɹɪmeɪnd, ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪm əz i meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə ðə ɹumz i hæd kleɪmd ɪn ðə mænʃən.

They scattered. Only the Aiel remained, guarding him as he made his way to the rooms he had claimed in the mansion.

ə ʃɔɹt taɪm lɔŋɡɝ. hi oʊnli hæd tə kip θɪŋz bælənst ə ʃɔɹt taɪm lɔŋɡɝ. ðən ɪt kəɾ ɛnd.

A short time longer. He only had to keep things balanced a short time longer. Then it could end.

ən i faʊn ðəɾ i wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ðəɾ ɛn əz mʌtʃ əz luz θɝɪn dɪd.

And he found that he was beginning to look forward to that end as much as Lews Therin did.

jə pɹɑməst wi kəd daɪ, luz θɝɪn sɛd bɪtwin dɪstən sɑbz.

You promised we could die, Lews Therin said between distant sobs.

aɪ dɪd, ɹænd sɛd. ən wi wɪl.

I did, Rand said. And we will.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾitu

CHAPTER 32

ɹɪvɝz ə ʃædoʊ nɪneɪiv stʊɾ ɑn ðə bɹɔd wɔl ɝaʊn bændɑɹ ɛbən, lʊkɪŋ daʊn oʊvɝ ðə dɑɹkən sɪɾi. ðə wɔl wɑz ɑn ði ɪnlæn saɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, bʌt bændɑɹ ɛbən wɑz bɪlt ɑn ə sloʊp, soʊ ʃi kəd si aʊɾ oʊvɝ ɪt, pæs ðə sɪɾi, təwɔɹd ði oʊʃən bɪɑnd. ðə naɪt fɑɡ ɹoʊld ɪn əkɹɔs ðə wɔɾɝz, hæŋɪŋ əbʌv ə kɹɪsp blæk mɪɹɝ si. ɪt sim laɪk ə ɹəflɛkʃən ə ðə klaʊdz haɪ əbʌv. ðoʊz klaʊdz ɡloʊd wɪð ə fæntəm pɝl laɪt, kæs baɪ ə mun ʃi kəd nɑt si.

Rivers of Shadow Nynaeve stood on the broad wall around Bandar Eban, looking down over the darkened city. The wall was on the inland side of the city, but Bandar Eban was built on a slope, so she could see out over it, past the city, toward the ocean beyond. The night fog rolled in across the waters, hanging above a crisp black mirror sea. It seemed like a reflection of the clouds high above. Those clouds glowed with a phantom pearl light, cast by a moon she could not see.

ðə fɑɡ dɪd nɑt ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi; ɪt ɹɛɹli dɪd. ɪt hʌŋ oʊvɝ ði oʊʃən, tʃɝnɪŋ. laɪk ðə ɡoʊst ʌv ə fɔɹəs faɪɝ, stɑp baɪ səm ənsin bæɹiɝ.

The fog did not reach the city; it rarely did. It hung over the ocean, churning. Like the ghost of a forest fire, stopped by some unseen barrier.

ʃi kəd stɪl fil ðə stɔɹm tə ðə nɔɹθ. ɪt kɔld ɑn əɹ tə ɹaɪd θɹu ðə stʃɹits, ʃaʊɾɪŋ wɔɹnɪŋ. fli tə ðə sɛlɝz! stɔɹ ʌp fud, fəɹ ə dɪzæstɝ wɪl stʃɹaɪk! ənfɔɹtʃənətli, pækɪŋ ɝθ əɹ ɹiɪnfɔɹsɪŋ wɔlz wəd nɑt hɛlp əɡɛns ðɪs tɛmpəst. ɪt wɑz ʌv ə dɪfɹən sɔɹɾ ɪntaɪɝli.

She could still feel the storm to the north. It called on her to ride through the streets, shouting warning. Flee to the cellars! Store up food, for a disaster will strike! Unfortunately, packing earth or reinforcing walls would not help against this tempest. It was of a different sort entirely.

ði oʊʃən fɑɡ wɑz ɔfən hɛɹəl tə wɪnz, ən ðɪs naɪt wɑz noʊ ɪksɛpʃən. ʃi pʊld əɹ ʃɔl kloʊs, smɛlɪŋ bɹaɪn ɑn ði ɛɹ. ɪt mɪkst wɪð ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl sɛns ʌv ən oʊvɝkɹaʊɾɪd sɪɾi. ɹɛfjus, pæk bɑɾiz, sʊɾ ən smoʊk fɹəm faɪɝz ən stoʊvz. ʃi mɪs ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ðə wɪnz ðəɹ wɝ koʊld ɪn ðə wɪntɝz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɔlweɪz fɹɛʃ. bændɑɹ ɛbənz wɪnz ɔlweɪz fɛl slaɪtli juzd.

The ocean fog was often herald to winds, and this night was no exception. She pulled her shawl close, smelling brine on the air. It mixed with the inevitable scents of an overcrowded city. Refuse, packed bodies, soot and smoke from fires and stoves. She missed the Two Rivers. The winds there were cold in the winters, but they were always fresh. Bandar Eban's winds always felt slightly used.

ðəɹ wəd nɛvɝ əɡɛn bi ə pleɪs fəɹ əɹ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ʃi nu ðɪs, ðoʊ ɪt hɝt hɝ.

There would never again be a place for her in the Two Rivers. She knew this, though it hurt her.

ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ naʊ; ɪt hæd bɪkʌm u ʃi wɑz, mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ naʊ ðən biɪŋ wɪzdəm hæd wʌns bɪn. wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ʃi kəd hil pipəl ɪn ə weɪ ðət stɪl simd ə mɑɹvəl. ən wɪð ði əθɔɹəɾi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ bɪhaɪn hɝ, ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz ɪn ðə wɝld, mætʃt oʊnli baɪ ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ən ði əkeɪʒənəl mɑnɑɹk.

She was Aes Sedai now; it had become who she was, more important to her now than being Wisdom had once been. With the One Power, she could Heal people in a way that still seemed a marvel. And with the authority of the White Tower behind her, she was one of the most powerful individuals in the world, matched only by other sisters and the occasional monarch.

ən ɪn ɹəɡɑɹd tə mɑnɑɹks, ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz mɛɹid tə ə kɪŋ. hi maɪt nɑɾ əv ə kɪŋdəm, bʌt læn wɑz ə kɪŋ. tə hɝ, ɪf noʊbɑdi ɛls. laɪf ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wəd nɑt sut hɪm. ænd, tʃɹuθfəli, ɪt wʊdn suɾ əɹ iðɝ. ðət sɪmpəl laɪf - wʌns ɔl ʃi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə ɪmædʒən - wəd naʊ sim dʌl ən ənfʌlfɪlɪŋ.

And in regard to monarchs, she herself was married to a king. He might not have a kingdom, but Lan was a king. To her, if nobody else. Life in the Two Rivers would not suit him. And, truthfully, it wouldn't suit her either. That simple life - once all she had been able to imagine - would now seem dull and unfulfilling.

stɪl, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl nɑt tə fil wɪsfəl, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə naɪt fɑɡz.

Still, it was difficult not to feel wistful, particularly when watching the night fogs.

"ðɛɹ," mɛɹaɪs sɛd, vɔɪs ɛdʒd wɪð tɛnʃən. ʃi, əlɔŋ wɪð kædzueɪn ən kɔɹəl, stʊd lʊkɪŋ ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən - nɑt saʊθwɛst oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi ən oʊʃən, bʌɾ ist. nɪneɪiv hæɾ ɔlmoʊs dɪsaɪɾɪd əɡɛnst əkʌmpəniɪŋ ðə ɡɹup, əz ʃi hæd lɪɾəl daʊt ðət kædzueɪn pɑɹtli bleɪm nɪneɪiv fəɹ əɹ ɛɡzaɪl. haʊɛvɝ, ðə pɹɑspɛkt ə siɪŋ ði æpɹɪʃənz hæd bɪn tu ɛntaɪsɪŋ.

"There," Merise said, voice edged with tension. She, along with Cadsuane and Corele, stood looking in the other direction - not southwest over the city and ocean, but east. Nynaeve had almost decided against accompanying the group, as she had little doubt that Cadsuane partly blamed Nynaeve for her exile. However, the prospect of seeing the apparitions had been too enticing.

nɪneɪiv tɝn fɹəm ðə sɪɾi ən kɹɔs ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ði ʌðɝz. kɔɹəl ɡlænst ət hɝ, bʌt mɛɹaɪs ən kædzueɪn ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ. ðət suɾəd nɪneɪiv. ðoʊ ɪt dɪd kəntɪnju tə ɝk əɹ ðət kɔɹəl - ʌv ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ - wɑz soʊ ɡɑɹɾəd ɪn əɹ æksɛptəns ə nɪneɪiv. kɔɹəl wɑz plɛzənt, kənsoʊlɪŋ, jɛt stɝnli ənwɪlɪŋ tə ədmɪt ðət nɪneɪiv wɑz ɔlsoʊ ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə jɛloʊ. wɛl, ðə wʊmən wəɾ əv tə tʃeɪnʒ ɹʌts ɪvɛntʃəwəli, wʌns ɛɡwin sɪkjʊɹd ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Nynaeve turned from the city and crossed the top of the wall, joining the others. Corele glanced at her, but Merise and Cadsuane ignored her. That suited Nynaeve. Though it did continue to irk her that Corele - of the Yellow Ajah - was so guarded in her acceptance of Nynaeve. Corele was pleasant, consoling, yet sternly unwilling to admit that Nynaeve was also a member of the Yellow. Well, the woman would have to change ruts eventually, once Egwene secured the White Tower.

nɪneɪiv pɪɹd θɹu ðə kɹɛnɛleɪʃənz ətɑp ðə wɔl, skænɪŋ ðə dɑɹk lændskeɪp aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. ʃi kəd feɪnli meɪk aʊt ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðə ʃæntiz ðət hæd kɹaʊɾəd ʌp əɡɛns ðə wɔlz əntɪl ɹisənli. ðə deɪnʒɝz - səm ɹil, ʌðɝz ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd - ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd hæd kɑz moʊst ə ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz tə kɹaʊɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾiz stʃɹits. dilɪŋ wɪð ðɛm, ən ðə dɪziz ən hʌŋɡɝ ðeɪ bɹɔt wɪð ðɛm, stɪl dɪmændəɾ ə lɑɾ ə ɹændz taɪm.

Nynaeve peered through the crenellations atop the wall, scanning the dark landscape outside the city. She could faintly make out the remnants of the shanties that had crowded up against the walls until recently. The dangers - some real, others exaggerated - in the countryside had caused most of the refugees to crowd into the city's streets. Dealing with them, and the disease and hunger they brought with them, still demanded a lot of Rand's time.

aʊt bɪɑn ðət tʃɹæmpəld-daʊn ʃæntitaʊn ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ʃɹʌbz, stʌntɪd tʃɹiz, ə ʃæɾoʊd bɪɾ ə bɹoʊkən tɪmbɝ ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ə wæɡən wil. ðə nɪɹbaɪ filz wɝ bæɹən. plaʊd, siɾəd, jɛt stɪl bæɹən. laɪt! waɪ dɪdn kɹɑps ɡɹoʊ ɛnimɔɹ? wɛɹ wəd ðeɪ faɪn fud ðɪs wɪntɝ?

Out beyond that trampled-down shantytown there were only shrubs, stunted trees, a shadowed bit of broken timber that might have been a wagon wheel. The nearby fields were barren. Plowed, seeded, yet still barren. Light! Why didn't crops grow anymore? Where would they find food this winter?

ɛniweɪ, ðət wɑznt wʌt ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ət ðə moʊmənt. wʌt wɑz ɪt mɛɹaɪs hæd sin?

Anyway, that wasn't what she was looking for at the moment. What was it Merise had seen?

wɛɹ -  ðən nɪneɪiv sɔ ɪt. laɪk ə wɪsp ə ði oʊʃən fɑɡ, ə taɪni pætʃ ʌv ɡloʊɪŋ laɪt wɑz bloʊɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɪt ɡɹu, bʌlʒɪŋ laɪk ə taɪni stɔɹm klaʊd, ɡloʊɪŋ wɪð ə pɝli laɪt nɑɾ ənlaɪk ðəɾ ə ðə klaʊdz əbʌv. ɪt ɹizɑlvd ɪndə ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə mæn, wɔkɪŋ. ðən ðət lumənɛsən fɑɡ spɹaʊɾəd mɔɹ fɪɡjɝz. wɪðɪn moʊməns, ən ɪntaɪɝ ɡloʊɪŋ pɹəsɛʃən stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə dɑɹk ɡɹaʊnd, muvɪŋ əɾ ə mɔɹnfəl peɪs.

Where -  Then Nynaeve saw it. Like a wisp of the ocean fog, a tiny patch of glowing light was blowing across the ground. It grew, bulging like a tiny storm cloud, glowing with a pearly light not unlike that of the clouds above. It resolved into the shape of a man, walking. Then that luminescent fog sprouted more figures. Within moments, an entire glowing procession strode across the dark ground, moving at a mournful pace.

nɪneɪiv ʃɪvɝd, ðən stɝnli ɹɛpɹəmændɪd hɝsɛlf. spɪɹəts fɹəm ðə dɛd ðeɪ maɪt bi, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ noʊ deɪnʒɝ soʊ fɑɹ əweɪ. bʌt tʃɹaɪ əz ʃi maɪt, ʃi kəd nɑt bænɪʃ ðə ɡus bʌmps fɹəm əɹ ɑɹmz.

Nynaeve shivered, then sternly reprimanded herself. Spirits from the dead they might be, but they were no danger so far away. But try as she might, she could not banish the goose bumps from her arms.

ðə pɹəsɛʃən wɑz tu dɪstən fəɹ əɹ tə meɪk aʊt mɛni dɪteɪlz. ðəɹ wɝ boʊθ mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn ðə laɪn, klæɾ ɪn ɡloʊɪŋ kloʊðɪŋ ðət floʊɾ ən ʃɪmɝd laɪk ðə sɪɾiz bænɝz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kʌlɝ tə ði æpɹɪʃənz, dʒʌs pælnəs, ənlaɪk moʊst ə ðə ɡoʊsts ðət hæd bɪn əpɪɹɪŋ leɪtli.

The procession was too distant for her to make out many details. There were both men and women in the line, clad in glowing clothing that flowed and shimmered like the city's banners. There was no color to the apparitions, just paleness, unlike most of the ghosts that had been appearing lately.

ðiz wɝ kəmpoʊz kəmplitli ʌv ə stʃɹeɪnʒ, ʌðɝwɝldli laɪt. sɛvɹəl fɪɡjɝz ɪn ðə ɡɹup -  wɪtʃ wɑz naʊ əbaʊt tu hʌnʒɹəd stʃɹɔŋ - wɝ kæɹiɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ əbdʒɛkt. səm kaɪndə pɑlɑnkwɪn?

These were composed completely of a strange, otherworldly light. Several figures in the group -  which was now about two hundred strong - were carrying a large object. Some kind of palanquin?

əɹ . . . noʊ. ɪt wɑz ə kɔfɪn. wɑz ðɪs ə fjunɝəl pɹəsɛʃən fɹəm lɔŋ əɡoʊ, ðɛn? wʌt hæd hæpən tə ðiz pipəl, ən waɪ hæd ðeɪ bɪn dʒɹɔn bæk tə ðə wɝld ə ðə lɪvɪŋ?

Or . . . no. It was a coffin. Was this a funeral procession from long ago, then? What had happened to these people, and why had they been drawn back to the world of the living?

ɹumɝz ɪn ðə sɪɾi sɛd ðə pɹəsɛʃən hæd fɝst əpɪɹd ðə naɪɾ æftɝ ɹænd ɝaɪvd ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən. ðə wɔlz ɡɑɹdz, hu wɝ laɪkli ðə moʊst ɹɪlaɪəbəl, hæd kənfɝm ðət tə hɝ ɪn ənizi vɔɪsəz.

Rumors in the city said the procession had first appeared the night after Rand arrived in Bandar Eban. The wall's guards, who were likely the most reliable, had confirmed that to her in uneasy voices.

"aɪ də nɑt si ðə ɹizən fəɹ soʊ mʌtʃ fʌs," mɛɹaɪs sɛd wɪð əɹ tæɹɑbənɝ æksɛnt, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "ɡoʊsts, wəɹ ɔl əkʌstəm tə ðɛm baɪ naʊ, ɑɹ wi nɑt? ət lis ðiz ɑɹən kɑzɪŋ pipəl tə mɛlt əɹ bɝst ɪndə fleɪmz."

"I do not see the reason for so much fuss," Merise said with her Taraboner accent, folding her arms. "Ghosts, we are all accustomed to them by now, are we not? At least these aren't causing people to melt or burst into flames."

ɹɪpɔɹts ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət "ɪnsəɾənts" wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ fɹikwənt. dʒʌst ɪn ðə læs fju deɪz, nɪneɪiv hæɾ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾəd θɹi kɹɛɾəbəl ɹɪpɔɹts ə pipəl u hæd hæɾ ɪnsɛks bɝoʊ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ skɪn, kɪlɪŋ ðɛm. ðəɹ hæɾ ɔlsoʊ bɪn ðə mæn u hæd bɪn faʊn ɪn ɪz bɛd wʌn mɔɹnɪŋ, kəmplitli tʃeɪnʒd ɪndə bɝn tʃɑɹkoʊl. hɪz lɪnənz hædn bɪn sɪŋʒd. ʃi hæd sin ðət bɑɾi hɝsɛlf.

Reports in the city indicated that "incidents" were growing more and more frequent. Just in the last few days, Nynaeve had investigated three credible reports of people who had had insects burrow out of their skin, killing them. There had also been the man who had been found in his bed one morning, completely changed into burned charcoal. His linens hadn't been singed. She had seen that body herself.

ðiz ɪnsəɾənts wɝn kɑz baɪ ðə ɡoʊsts, bʌt ðə pipəl hæd bɪɡʌn tə bleɪm ði æpɹɪʃənz.

These incidents weren't caused by the ghosts, but the people had begun to blame the apparitions.

bɛɾɝ ðən əm bleɪmɪŋ ɹænd, ʃi səpoʊzd.

Better than them blaming Rand, she supposed.

"ðɪs weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ɪts fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ," mɛɹaɪs kəntɪnjud.

"This waiting in the city, it is frustrating," Merise continued.

"aʊɝ taɪm ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi dʌz sim tə læk fɹut," kɔɹəl əɡɹid. "wi ʃəd bi muvɪŋ ɑn. juv hɝd ðət hiz pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ ðət ðə læs bæɾəl wɪl bɪɡɪn sun."

"Our time in this city does seem to lack fruit," Corele agreed. "We should be moving on. You've heard that he is proclaiming that the Last Battle will begin soon."

nɪneɪiv fɛlt ə stæb ʌv wɝi fəɹ læn, ðən æŋɡɝ təwɔɹd ɹænd. hi stɪl θɔt ðəɾ ɪf i kəd steɪdʒ ɪz əsɔlt ət ðə seɪm taɪm əz lænz ətæk ɑn tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp, hi kəd kənfjuz ɪz ɛnəmiz.

Nynaeve felt a stab of worry for Lan, then anger toward Rand. He still thought that if he could stage his assault at the same time as Lan's attack on Tarwin's Gap, he could confuse his enemies.

lænz ətæk kəd vɛɹi wɛl bi ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə læs bæɾəl. waɪ, ðɛn, wʊdn ɹænd kəmɪt tʃɹups tə hɛlp?

Lan's attack could very well be the beginning of the Last Battle. Why, then, wouldn't Rand commit troops to help?

"jɛs," kædzueɪn sɛd, mjuzɪŋli, "hi ɪz pɹɑbli ɹaɪt." waɪ dɪd ʃi kip ðət hʊɾ ʌp? ɹænd ɑbviəsli wɑzn ɝaʊnd.

"Yes," Cadsuane said, musingly, "he is probably right." Why did she keep that hood up? Rand obviously wasn't around.

"ðɛn wɪv ɔl ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɹizən tə muv ɑn," mɛɹaɪs sɛd stɝnli. "ɹæn ælθɹ, hiz ə ful! ən ɑɹæd dumən, ɪts ɪɹɛləvənt. ə kɪŋ əɹ noʊ kɪŋ? wʌt dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ?"

"Then we have all the greater reason to move on," Merise said sternly. "Rand al'Thor, he is a fool! And Arad Doman, it is irrelevant. A king or no king? What does it matter?"

"ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪɹɛləvənt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, snɪfɪŋ. "wʌɾ ə ðɛm? jə wəɾ əv əs mɑɹtʃ tə ðə blaɪɾ ən liv əɹ kɪŋdəmz oʊpən tə ɪnveɪʒən?"

"The Seanchan are not irrelevant," Nynaeve said, sniffing. "What of them? You would have us march to the Blight and leave our kingdoms open to invasion?"

mɛɹaɪs dɪdn ɹiækt. kɔɹəl smaɪld ən ʃɹʌɡd, ðən lʊk təwɔɹd deɪmɝ flɪn, hu lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl bɪhaɪn ðɛm, hɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəd. ðə lɛðɝi oʊl mænz kæʒəwəl pɑstʃɝ sədʒɛstəd ðəɾ i sɔ ðə pɹəsɛʃən ʌv ɡoʊsts əz nʌθɪŋ spɛʃəl. ən ðiz deɪz, hi maɪt bi ɹaɪt.

Merise didn't react. Corele smiled and shrugged, then looked toward Damer Flinn, who leaned against the wall behind them, his arms folded. The leathery old man's casual posture suggested that he saw the procession of ghosts as nothing special. And these days, he might be right.

nɪneɪiv lʊk bæk aʊɾ ət ðə ɡoʊs pɹəsɛʃən, hu wɝ wɔkɪŋ ɪn ən ɑɹk, ɹaʊndɪŋ ðə sɪɾi wɔl. ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪzum ðɛɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən, mɛɹaɪs ən kɔɹəl teɪkɪŋ fɝðɝ ɑpɝtunəɾi tə vɔɪs ðɛɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ wɪð ɹænd ɪn ðɛɹ sɛpɹət weɪz - wʌn daʊɝ, ði ʌðɝ kəndʒinjəl.

Nynaeve looked back out at the ghost procession, who were walking in an arc, rounding the city wall. The other Aes Sedai resumed their conversation, Merise and Corele taking further opportunity to voice their displeasure with Rand in their separate ways - one dour, the other congenial.

ɪt meɪd nɪneɪiv wɑnə dɪfɛn hɪm. ðoʊ hi hæd bɪn dɪfəkəlt ən ɪɹæɾɪk leɪtli, ðəɹ wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɝk fəɹ ɪm tə də ɪn ɑɹæd dumən. ðə miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə sintʃæn ɪn fɑlm wɑz oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt taɪm əweɪ. bɪɑn ðæt, ɹænd wɑz ɹaɪt tə wɝi əbaʊt fɪlɪŋ ðə dəmɑni θɹoʊn. ən wʌɾ ɪf ɡɹeɪndəl ɹɪli wɑz hɪɹ, əz i sim tə θɪŋk? ði ʌðɝz θɔɾ i mʌs bi mɪsteɪkən əbaʊt ðə fɔɹseɪkən, bʌt ɹænd hæd dɪskʌvɝd fɔɹseɪkən ɪn nɪɹli ɛvɹi ʌðɝ kɪŋdəm. waɪ nɑɾ ɑɹæd dumən?

It made Nynaeve want to defend him. Though he had been difficult and erratic lately, there was important work for him to do in Arad Doman. The meeting with the Seanchan in Falme was only a short time away. Beyond that, Rand was right to worry about filling the Domani throne. And what if Graendal really was here, as he seemed to think? The others thought he must be mistaken about the Forsaken, but Rand had discovered Forsaken in nearly every other kingdom. Why not Arad Doman?

ə mɪsɪŋ kɪŋ, ə læn siθɪŋ wɪð kənfjuʒən, fæmən ən stʃɹaɪf? ðiz θɪŋz saʊndəɾ ɪɡzækli laɪk ðə kaɪnz ə tʃɹʌbəl wʌn wəd dɪskʌvɝ nɪɹ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

A missing king, a land seething with confusion, famine and strife? These things sounded exactly like the kinds of trouble one would discover near one of the Forsaken.

ði ʌðɝz kəntɪnjud tə tɔk. nɪneɪiv stɑɹɾəd tə liv, ən əz ʃi dɪd soʊ ʃi noʊɾəst ðət kædzueɪn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ. nɪneɪiv hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kloʊkt wʊmən. kædzueɪnz feɪs wɑz bɛɹli vɪzəbəl baɪ tɔɹtʃlaɪt, bʌt nɪneɪiv kɑɾ ə ɡɹɪmɑs ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, əz ɪf kædzueɪn wɝ dɪsplizd wɪð mɛɹaɪsəz ən kɔɹəlz kəmpleɪns. nɪneɪiv ən kædzueɪn stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ fəɹ ə moʊmənt; ðən kædzueɪn nɑɾəd kɝtli. ði eɪdʒɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ tɝn ən bɪɡæn tə wɔk əweɪ, ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv wʌn ə mɛɹaɪsəz taɪɹeɪdz əbaʊt ɹænd.

The others continued to talk. Nynaeve started to leave, and as she did so she noticed that Cadsuane was watching her. Nynaeve hesitated, turning toward the cloaked woman. Cadsuane's face was barely visible by torchlight, but Nynaeve caught a grimace in the shadows, as if Cadsuane were displeased with Merise's and Corele's complaints. Nynaeve and Cadsuane stared at each other for a moment; then Cadsuane nodded curtly. The aged Aes Sedai turned and began to walk away, right in the middle of one of Merise's tirades about Rand.

ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ bʌsəl tə kætʃ ʌp. wʌt hæd ðət lʊk bɪn fɔɹ? kædzueɪn hæɾ ə hæbəɾ ə tʃɹiɾɪŋ ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ lɛs wɝði ʌv ɹɪspɛk ðən ə kɑmən mjul. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ɔl ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm wɝ mɪɹ tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn əɹ aɪz.

The other Aes Sedai bustled to catch up. What had that look been for? Cadsuane had a habit of treating other Aes Sedai as if they were less worthy of respect than a common mule. It was as if all the rest of them were mere children in her eyes.

bʌt, wɛl, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə weɪ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn æktɪŋ leɪtli. . . .

But, well, considering the way many Aes Sedai had been acting lately. . . .

fɹaʊnɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, nɪneɪiv lɛft ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə wɔl ɡɑɹdz. ðət nɑɾ ə kædzueɪnz kʊdn pɑsəbli hæv bɪn ɡɪvən aʊɾ ə ɹɪspɛkt. kædzueɪn wɑz fɑɹ tu sɛlf-ɹaɪtʃəs ən ɛɹəɡən fəɹ ðæt.

Frowning to herself, Nynaeve left in the other direction, nodding to the wall guards. That nod of Cadsuane's couldn't possibly have been given out of respect. Cadsuane was far too self-righteous and arrogant for that.

wʌt tə də əbaʊt ɹænd, ðɛn? hi dɪdnt wɑnt nɪneɪivz hɛlp - əɹ ɛniwʌnz hɛlp - bʌt ðət wɑz nʌθɪŋ nu. hid bɪn dʒʌst əz stʌbɝn əz ə ʃifɝɾɝ bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən ɪz fɑðɝ hæd bɪn nɪɹli əz bæd. ðət hæd nɛvɝ stɑp nɪneɪiv ðə wɪzdəm, soʊ ɪt sɝɾənli wʊdn stɑp nɪneɪiv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃid ɹæŋɡəl kɑplɪnz ən kɔŋɡɝz; ʃi kəd də ðə seɪm fəɹ tʃɹʌmpt-ʌp ɹænd ælθɹ. ʃi hæd hæf ə maɪn tə stʃɹaɪd tə hɪz nu "pæləs" ən ɡɪv ɪm ən ɪɹfəl.

What to do about Rand, then? He didn't want Nynaeve's help - or anyone's help - but that was nothing new. He'd been just as stubborn as a sheepherder back in the Two Rivers, and his father had been nearly as bad. That had never stopped Nynaeve the Wisdom, so it certainly wouldn't stop Nynaeve the Aes Sedai. She'd wrangled Coplins and Congars; she could do the same for trumped-up Rand al'Thor. She had half a mind to stride to his new "palace" and give him an earful.

ɪksɛpt . . . ɹænd ælθɹ wɑzn dʒʌst ɛni kɑplɪn əɹ kɔŋɡɝ. stʌbɝn foʊks bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz hædn hæd ɹændz stʃɹeɪnʒli mɛnəsɪŋ ɔɹə.

Except . . . Rand al'Thor wasn't just any Coplin or Congar. Stubborn folks back in the Two Rivers hadn't had Rand's strangely menacing aura.

ʃid dɛlt wɪð deɪnʒɝəs mɛn bɪfɔɹ. hɝ oʊn læn wɑz əz deɪnʒɝəs əz ə wʊlf ɑn ðə pɹaʊl, ən kəd bi əz pɹɪkli, tu, ivən ɪf i wɑz ɡʊɾ ət haɪɾɪŋ ɪt fɹəm moʊs pipəl. bʌɾ əz θɹɛɾənɪŋ ən əz ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪŋ əz læn kəd bi, hid sunɝ tʃɑp ɔf ɪz oʊn hæn ðən ɹeɪz ɪt tə hɑɹm hɝ.

She'd dealt with dangerous men before. Her own Lan was as dangerous as a wolf on the prowl, and could be as prickly, too, even if he was good at hiding it from most people. But as threatening and as intimidating as Lan could be, he'd sooner chop off his own hand than raise it to harm her.

ɹænd wɑz dɪfɹənt. nɪneɪiv ɹitʃt ðə stɛps liɾɪŋ ɔf ðə wɔl ɪndə ðə sɪɾi ən hɛɾəd daʊn ðɛm, weɪvɪŋ əweɪ ə ɡɑɹdz sədʒɛstʃən ðət ʃi teɪk wʌn ə ðɛm ɪn ɛskɔɹt. ɪt wɑz naɪɾ ən ðəɹ wɝ ə lɑɾ ə ɹɛfjudʒiz əbaʊt, bʌt ʃi wɑz hɑɹdli hɛlpləs. ʃi dɪɾ æksɛpt ə læntɝn fɹəm ənʌðɝ ɡɑɹd, haʊɛvɝ. juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə kɹæf laɪt wəd meɪk ðə pæsɝzbi ənkʌmftəɹbəl.

Rand was different. Nynaeve reached the steps leading off the wall into the city and headed down them, waving away a guard's suggestion that she take one of them in escort. It was night and there were a lot of refugees about, but she was hardly helpless. She did accept a lantern from another guard, however. Using the One Power to craft light would make the passersby uncomfortable.

ɹænd. wʌns, ʃid θɔɾ ɪm əz dʒɛntəl əz læn. hɪz dɪvoʊʃən tə pɹətɛktɪŋ wɪmən hæd bɪn ɔlmoʊs læfəbəl ɪn ɪts ɪnəsəns. ðət ɹænd wɑz ɡɔn. nɪneɪiv sɔ əɡɛn ðə moʊmənt wən i hæɾ ɛɡzaɪl kædzueɪn. ʃid bɪliv ðəɾ i wəd kɪl kædzueɪn ɪf i sɔ hɝ feɪs əɡɛn, ən θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə moʊmən stɪl ɡeɪv əɹ ʃɪvɝz. ʃʊɹli ɪt hæd bɪn əɹ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, bʌt ðə ɹum hæd sim tə dɑɹkən dɪstɪŋkli ət ðət moʊmənt, əz ɪf ə klaʊd hæd pæst oʊvɝ ðə sʌn.

Rand. Once, she'd thought him as gentle as Lan. His devotion to protecting women had been almost laughable in its innocence. That Rand was gone. Nynaeve saw again the moment when he had exiled Cadsuane. She'd believed that he would kill Cadsuane if he saw her face again, and thinking of the moment still gave her shivers. Surely it had been her imagination, but the room had seemed to darken distinctly at that moment, as if a cloud had passed over the sun.

ɹænd ælθɹ hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl. hɪz ɪksploʊʒən ə tɛmpɝ ət nɪneɪiv hɝsɛlf ə fju deɪz əɡoʊ wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ ɪɡzæmpəl. ʌv kɔɹs, hi wəd nɛvɝ ɛɡzaɪl əɹ θɹɛɾən hɝ, dɪspaɪt wʌɾ i hæd sɛd. hi wɑzn ðət hɑɹd. wɑz hi?

Rand al'Thor had grown unpredictable. His explosion of temper at Nynaeve herself a few days ago was just another example. Of course, he would never exile or threaten her, despite what he had said. He wasn't that hard. Was he?

ʃi ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə stoʊn stɛps, wɔkɪŋ aʊɾ ɑntu ə bɔɹdwɔk steɪnd wɪð ðə mʌɾ ʌv ivnɪŋ tʃɹæfɪk. ʃi pʊld əɹ ʃɔl kloʊs. hʌɾəld pipəl klʌstɝɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit.

She reached the bottom of the stone steps, walking out onto a boardwalk stained with the mud of evening traffic. She pulled her shawl close. Huddled people clustered on the other side of the street.

ðə ʃɑp ɛntʃɹənsəz ən æliweɪz ðəɹ ɔfɝd pɹətɛkʃən fɹəm ðə wɪnd.

The shop entrances and alleyways there offered protection from the wind.

ʃi hɝɾ ə tʃaɪl kɑf əmʌŋ ə dɪstənt ɡɹup. ʃi fɹoʊz, ðən hɝd ðə kɑf əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ən izi saʊnd. mʌɾɝɪŋ, ʃi kɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, ðən fɔɹst əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp əɹ læntɝn tə ɪlumɪnɪt wʌn ɡɹup ə dʒɹaʊzi pipəl æftɝ ənʌðɝ. mɛni hæd ðə kɑpɝi skɪn ə ðə dəmɑni, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə tæɹɑbənɝz əz wɛl. ən . . . wɝ ðoʊz sɑldəiənz? ðət wɑz ʌnɪkspɛktɪd.

She heard a child cough among a distant group. She froze, then heard the cough again. It was not an easy sound. Muttering, she crossed the street, then forced her way through the refugees, holding up her lantern to illuminate one group of drowsy people after another. Many had the coppery skin of the Domani, but there were a fair number of Taraboners as well. And . . . were those Saldaeans? That was unexpected.

moʊst ə ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz leɪ ɪn ɹæɡəd blæŋkəts nɛks tə ðɛɹ miɡɝ pəzɛʃənz. ə pɑt hɪɹ, ə kwɪl ðɛɹ. wʌn jʌŋ ɡɝl hæɾ ə smɔl klɔθ dɑl ðət maɪɾ əv wʌns bɪn faɪn, bʌt hæd naʊ lɔst wʌn ʌv ɪts ɑɹmz. ɹænd sɝɾənli wɑz ɪfɛktɪv ət səbduɪŋ kʌntʃɹiz, bʌɾ ɪz kɪŋdəmz niɾəd mɔɹ ðən dʒʌs hændaʊts ʌv ɡɹeɪn. ðeɪ niɾəd stəbɪlɪɾi, ən ðeɪ niɾəd sʌmθɪŋ - sʌmwʌn - ðeɪ kəd bɪliv ɪn. ɹænd wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪnkɹisɪŋli bæɾ əɾ ɔfɝɪŋ iðɝ wʌn.

Most of the refugees lay in ragged blankets next to their meager possessions. A pot here, a quilt there. One young girl had a small cloth doll that might have once been fine, but had now lost one of its arms. Rand certainly was effective at subduing countries, but his kingdoms needed more than just handouts of grain. They needed stability, and they needed something - someone - they could believe in. Rand was getting increasingly bad at offering either one.

wɛɹ wɑz ðə sɔɹs ə ðət kɑf? fju ʌv ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz spoʊk tə hɝ, ən ðeɪ wɝ hɛzɪɾənt tə ænsɝ əɹ kwɛstʃənz. wən ʃi faɪnəli faʊn ðə bɔɪ, ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl ənɔɪd. hɪz pɛɹəns hæd meɪd ðɛɹ bɛdz ɪn ə hɑloʊ bɪtwin tu wʊɾən ʃɑps, ən əz nɪneɪiv əpɹoʊtʃt, ðə fɑðɝ stʊɾ ʌp tə kənfɹʌn hɝ. hi wɑz ə skɹʌfi dəmɑni wɪð ə dɑɹk, ɹæɡəd bɪɹɾ ən ə θɪk mʌstæʃ ðət maɪɾ əv wʌns bɪn tʃɹɪm tə dəmɑni fæʃən. hi wɔɹ noʊ koʊt, ən ɪz ʃɝt wɑz nɪɹli ɪn tæɾɝz.

Where was the source of that cough? Few of the refugees spoke to her, and they were hesitant to answer her questions. When she finally found the boy, she was more than a little annoyed. His parents had made their beds in a hollow between two wooden shops, and as Nynaeve approached, the father stood up to confront her. He was a scruffy Domani with a dark, ragged beard and a thick mustache that might have once been trimmed to Domani fashion. He wore no coat, and his shirt was nearly in tatters.

nɪneɪiv stɛɹɾ ɪm daʊn wɪð ə lʊk ʃi hæd lɝn lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ əɹ deɪz əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Nynaeve stared him down with a look she had learned long before her days as an Aes Sedai.

ɑnəsli, mɛn kəd bi soʊ fulɪʃ! hɪz sʌn wɑz laɪkli daɪɪŋ, ən jɛɾ i kənfɹʌntəd wʌn ə ðə fju pipəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi hu kəd hɛlp. ðə waɪf hæd mɔɹ sɛns, wɪtʃ wɑz juʒəwəli ðə keɪs. ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ hʌzbənz lɛɡ, kɑzɪŋ ɪm tə ɡlæns daʊn. hi faɪnəli tɝn əweɪ wɪð ə kwaɪət mʌɾɝ.

Honestly, men could be so foolish! His son was likely dying, and yet he confronted one of the few people in the city who could help. The wife had more sense, which was usually the case. She laid a hand on her husband's leg, causing him to glance down. He finally turned away with a quiet mutter.

ðə waɪfs fitʃɝz wɝ dɪfəkəl tə si θɹu ðə ɡɹaɪm ɑn əɹ feɪs. ðə dɝt wɑz stʃɹikt wɪð tɛɹ laɪnz ɑn əɹ tʃiks; ʃi hæɾ ɑbviəsli hæɾ ə dɪfəkəl kʌpəl ə naɪts.

The wife's features were difficult to see through the grime on her face. The dirt was streaked with tear lines on her cheeks; she had obviously had a difficult couple of nights.

nɪneɪiv nɛlt - ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə lumɪŋ fɑðɝ - ðən pʊl bæk ðə blæŋkət fɹəm ðə feɪs ə ðə tʃaɪld ɪn ðə wʊmənz ɑɹmz. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, hi wɑz ɡɔn ən peɪl, ən ɪz aɪz flʌɾɝd oʊpən ɪn səm dɪluʒən.

Nynaeve knelt - ignoring the looming father - then pulled back the blanket from the face of the child in the woman's arms. Sure enough, he was gaunt and pale, and his eyes fluttered open in some delusion.

"haʊ lɔŋ əz i bɪn kɑfɪŋ?" nɪneɪiv sɛd, pʊlɪŋ ə fju pækɪts ə ɝbz aʊɾ ə ðə paʊtʃ əɾ əɹ saɪd. ʃi dɪdn əv mʌtʃ, bʌt ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə du.

"How long has he been coughing?" Nynaeve said, pulling a few packets of herbs out of the pouch at her side. She didn't have much, but they would have to do.

"ə wik naʊ, leɪɾi," ðə wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd.

"A week now, Lady," the woman replied.

nɪneɪiv tskt ɪn ənɔɪəns, pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə nɪɹbaɪ tɪn kʌp. "fɪl ðæt," ʃi snæpt ət ðə fɑðɝ. "ju ɑɹ lʌki ðə bɔɪ hæz sɝvaɪv ðɪs lɔŋ wɪð ðə waɪt ʃeɪks; hi laɪkli wʊdn lɪv ðə naɪt wɪθaʊɾ ɪntɝvɛntʃən."

Nynaeve tsked in annoyance, pointing toward a nearby tin cup. "Fill that," she snapped at the father. "You are lucky the boy has survived this long with the white shakes; he likely wouldn't live the night without intervention."

dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ɝliɝ ɹɪlʌktəns, ðə fɑðɝ heɪsən tə oʊbeɪ, fɪlɪŋ ðə kʌp fɹəm ə nɪɹbaɪ bæɹəl. ət lis ðəɹ wɑzn ə læk ʌv wɔɾɝ hɪɹ, wɪð ðə fɹikwən ɹeɪnz.

Despite his earlier reluctance, the father hastened to obey, filling the cup from a nearby barrel. At least there wasn't a lack of water here, with the frequent rains.

nɪneɪiv tʊk ðə kʌp ən mɪks ði eɪsɛm ən fivɝbeɪn ɪn ɪt, ðən woʊv ə θɹɛɾ ə faɪɝ ən hiɾəd ðə wɔɾɝ. ɪt stɑɹɾəd stimɪŋ feɪnli, ən ðə fɑðɝ mʌɾɝd səm mɔɹ. nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd; ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz hɝd ðət ðə dəmɑni wɝ pɹæɡmæɾɪk pipəl wən ɪt keɪm tə juz ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ði ənɹɛst ɪn ðə sɪɾi mʌst ɹɪli bi ɡɛɾɪŋ tə ðɛm.

Nynaeve took the cup and mixed the acem and feverbane in it, then wove a thread of Fire and heated the water. It started steaming faintly, and the father muttered some more. Nynaeve shook her head; she'd always heard that the Domani were pragmatic people when it came to use of the One Power. The unrest in the city must really be getting to them.

"dʒɹɪŋk," ʃi sɛd tə ðə bɔɪ, nilɪŋ daʊn ən juzɪŋ ɔl faɪv paʊɝz ɪn ə kɑmplɛks wiv ə hilɪŋ ðət ʃi juzd ɪnstɪŋktɪvli. hɝ əbɪləɾi hæɾ ɔd səm ə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt hæɾ ɝn əɹ skɔɹn fɹəm ʌðɝz. iðɝ weɪ, hɝ mɛθəd wɝkt, ivən ɪf ʃi kʊdn ɪkspleɪn haʊ ʃi dɪd wʌt ʃi dɪd. ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə blɛsɪŋz ən ðə kɝsɪz ə biɪŋ ə waɪldɝ; ʃi kəd də θɪŋz baɪ ɪnstɪŋk ðəɾ ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ stʃɹʌɡəl tə lɝn. haʊɛvɝ, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl fəɹ nɪneɪiv tə ənlɝn səm ə ðə bæd hæbəts ʃid lɝnd.

"Drink," she said to the boy, kneeling down and using all five Powers in a complex weave of Healing that she used instinctively. Her ability had awed some of the other Aes Sedai, but had earned her scorn from others. Either way, her method worked, even if she couldn't explain how she did what she did. That was one of the blessings and the curses of being a wilder; she could do things by instinct that other Aes Sedai struggled to learn. However, it was difficult for Nynaeve to unlearn some of the bad habits she'd learned.

ðə bɔɪ, ðoʊ deɪzd, ɹɪspɑndɪd tə ðə kʌp pɹɛs tə hɪz lɪps. hɝ hilɪŋ wiv leɪ əkɹɔs ɪm əz i dʒɹæŋk, ən i stɪfənd, ɪnheɪlɪŋ ʃɑɹpli. ði ɝbz wɝnt niɾəd, bʌt ðeɪ wəd hɛlp ɡɪv ɪm stʃɹɛŋkθ fɑloʊɪŋ ðə ɹɪɡɝəs hilɪŋ. ʃid ɡɑɾən oʊvɝ əɹ hæbəɾ ʌv ɔlweɪz juzɪŋ ɝbz wən hilɪŋ, bʌt ʃi stɪl fɛl ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ pleɪs ən jusfəlnəs.

The boy, though dazed, responded to the cup pressed to his lips. Her Healing weave lay across him as he drank, and he stiffened, inhaling sharply. The herbs weren't needed, but they would help give him strength following the rigorous Healing. She'd gotten over her habit of always using herbs when Healing, but she still felt they had their place and usefulness.

ðə fɑðɝ nɛl daʊn θɹɛɾənɪŋli, bʌt nɪneɪiv pɹɛs ðə tɪps ə hɝ fɪŋɡɝz tə hɪz tʃɛst ən fɔɹst ɪm bæk. "ɡɪv ðə tʃaɪld ɛɹ."

The father knelt down threateningly, but Nynaeve pressed the tips of her fingers to his chest and forced him back. "Give the child air."

ðə bɔɪ blɪŋkt, ən nɪneɪiv kəd si sɛns flʌd bæk ɪndə hɪz aɪz. hi ʃɪvɝd wikli.

The boy blinked, and Nynaeve could see sense flood back into his eyes. He shivered weakly.

nɪneɪiv dɛlvd ɪm tə dətɝmən haʊ wɛl ðə hilɪŋ hæd wɝkt. "ðə fivɝ əz bɹoʊkən," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə nɑd, stændɪŋ ən ɹilisɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. "hi wɪl nid tə it wɛl oʊvɝ ðə nɛks fju deɪz; əl ɡɪv jəɹ dɪskɹɪpʃənz tə ðə dɑkmæstɝz, ən jəl ɹəsiv ɛkstʃɹə ɹæʃənz. də nɑt sɛl ðə fud, əɹ əl faɪn aʊt, ən əl bi æŋɡɹi. dʒju ʌndɝstænd?"

Nynaeve Delved him to determine how well the Healing had worked. "The fever has broken," she said with a nod, standing and releasing the One Power. "He will need to eat well over the next few days; I will give your descriptions to the dockmasters, and you will receive extra rations. Do not sell the food, or I will find out, and I will be angry. Do you understand?"

ðə wʊmən lʊk daʊn, əʃeɪmd. "wi wəd nɛvɝ. . . ."

The woman looked down, ashamed. "We would never. . . ."

"aɪ doʊn teɪk ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ ɡɹæntəɾ ɛnimɔɹ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ɛniweɪ, hi ʃəd lɪv, ɪf jə də əz aɪ seɪ. fiɾ ɪm ðə ɹɛst ə ðət dʒɹæf tənaɪt, baɪ sɪps ɪf juv tə. ɪf ðə fivɝ stɑɹts əɡɛn, bɹɪŋ ɪm tə mi ət ðə dʒɹæɡənz pæləs."

"I don't take anything for granted anymore," Nynaeve said. "Anyway, he should live, if you do as I say. Feed him the rest of that draught tonight, by sips if you have to. If the fever starts again, bring him to me at the Dragon's palace."

"jɛs, maɪ leɪɾi," ðə wʊmən sɛɾ əz ðə hʌzbənd nɛlt, teɪkɪŋ ðə bɔɪ ən smaɪlɪŋ.

"Yes, my Lady," the woman said as the husband knelt, taking the boy and smiling.

nɪneɪiv pɪkt ʌp əɹ læntɝn ən ɹoʊz.

Nynaeve picked up her lantern and rose.

"leɪɾi," ðə wʊmən sɛd. "θæŋk ju."

"Lady," the woman said. "Thank you."

nɪneɪiv tɝn bæk. "ju ʃʊɾə bɹɔɾ ɪm tə mi deɪz əɡoʊ. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ wʌt fulɪʃ supɝstɪʃənz pipəl ɑɹ spɹɛɾɪŋ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ nɑt jəɹ ɛnəmiz. ɪf jə noʊ ɛni hu ɑɹ sɪk, ɛnkɝɪdʒ əm tə vɪzəɾ ʌs."

Nynaeve turned back. "You should have brought him to me days ago. I don't care what foolish superstitions people are spreading, the Aes Sedai are not your enemies. If you know any who are sick, encourage them to visit us."

ðə wʊmən nɑɾəd, ən ðə hʌzbən sim kaʊd. nɪneɪiv stɔkt aʊɾ ə ði æliweɪ ən bæk ɑntu ðə dɑɹk stʃɹit, pæsɪŋ foʊk u wɑtʃt əɹ wɪð ə mɪkstʃɝ ʌv ɑ ən hɔɹɝ. fulɪʃ pipəl! wəd ðeɪ lɛt ðɛɹ oʊn tʃɪlʒɹən daɪ ɹæðɝ ðən ɡɛɾ əm hild?

The woman nodded, and the husband seemed cowed. Nynaeve stalked out of the alleyway and back onto the dark street, passing folk who watched her with a mixture of awe and horror. Foolish people! Would they let their own children die rather than get them Healed?

bæk ɑn ðə stʃɹit, nɪneɪiv kɑm hɝsɛlf. ðə daɪvɝʒən ɹɪli hædn teɪkən mʌtʃ ə hɝ taɪm, ən - tənaɪɾ ət list - taɪm wɑz wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz ʃi hæd plɛnti ʌv. ʃi wɑzn hævɪŋ mʌtʃ lʌk dilɪŋ wɪð ɹænd. hɝ oʊnli kɑnsəleɪʃən wɑz ðət kædzueɪn hæd dʌn wɝs əz ɪz ædvaɪzɝ.

Back on the street, Nynaeve calmed herself. The diversion really hadn't taken much of her time, and - tonight at least - time was one of the things she had plenty of. She wasn't having much luck dealing with Rand. Her only consolation was that Cadsuane had done worse as his advisor.

haʊ dɪd wʌn hændəl ə kɹitʃɝ laɪk ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? nɪneɪiv nu ðət ði oʊld ɹænd wɑz ðɛɹ, wɪðɪn ɪm sʌmwɛɹ. hi hæd sɪmpli bɪn biɾən ən kɪk soʊ mɛni taɪmz ðət hid ɡɔn ɪndə haɪɾɪŋ, lɛɾɪŋ ðɪs hɑɹʃɝ vɝʒən ɹul. əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt ɡæld əɹ tə ədmɪɾ ɪt, bʊliɪŋ ɪm wɑz dʒʌs nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə wɝk. bʌt haʊ wɑz ʃi tə ɡɛɾ ɪm tə də wʌɾ i ʃʊd, sɪns i wɑz tu bʊlhɛɾɪd tə ɹɪspɑn tə ɔɹɾənɛɹi pɹɑɾɪŋ?

How did one handle a creature like the Dragon Reborn? Nynaeve knew that the old Rand was there, within him somewhere. He had simply been beaten and kicked so many times that he'd gone into hiding, letting this harsher version rule. As much as it galled her to admit it, bullying him was just not going to work. But how was she to get him to do what he should, since he was too bullheaded to respond to ordinary prodding?

nɪneɪiv hɔltəd, læntɝn laɪɾ ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ən ɛmpti stʃɹit bɪfɔɹ hɝ. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn pɝsən u hæd mænədʒ tə wɝk wɪð ɹænd waɪl ət ðə seɪm taɪm titʃɪŋ ən tʃɹeɪnɪŋ hɪm. ɪt hædn bɪn kædzueɪn, nɔɹ hæɾ ɪt bɪn ɛni ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu tʃɹaɪd tə kæptʃɝ hɪm, tʃɹɪk ɪm əɹ bʊli hɪm.

Nynaeve halted, lantern light illuminating an empty street before her. There was one person who had managed to work with Rand while at the same time teaching and training him. It hadn't been Cadsuane, nor had it been any of the Aes Sedai who tried to capture him, trick him or bully him.

ɪt hæd bɪn mɔɪɹeɪn.

It had been Moiraine.

nɪneɪiv kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn əɹ weɪ. dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs mʌnθs ə hɝ laɪf, ðə blu hæɾ ɔl bʌt fɔn oʊvɝ ɹænd. ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɡɛɾ ɪm tə teɪk əɹ əz ɪz ædvaɪzɝ, ʃiɾ əɡɹid tə oʊbeɪ hɪz kəmænz ən ɔfɝ ædvaɪs oʊnli wən ɪt wɑz wɑntəd. wʌt ɡʊd wɑz ædvaɪs wən ɪt wɑz ɡɪvən oʊnli wən ɪt wɑz wɑntəd? pipəl niɾəd moʊs tə hɪɹ ði ædvaɪs ðeɪ dɪdnt wɑnt!

Nynaeve continued on her way. During the last months of her life, the Blue had all but fawned over Rand. In order to get him to take her as his advisor, she'd agreed to obey his commands and offer advice only when it was wanted. What good was advice when it was given only when it was wanted? People needed most to hear the advice they didn't want!

bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn hæd bɪn səksɛsfəl. θɹu hɝ, ɹænd hæd bɪɡʌn tə oʊvɝkʌm ɪz əvɝʒən tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɪθaʊt ɹændz əvɛntʃuəl æksɛptəns fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn, ɪt wɑz daʊtfəl ðət kædzueɪn wəɾ ɛvɝ əv meɪd hɛdweɪ ɪn bɪkʌmɪŋ ɪz kaʊnsəlɝ.

But Moiraine had been successful. Through her, Rand had begun to overcome his aversion to Aes Sedai. Without Rand's eventual acceptance for Moiraine, it was doubtful that Cadsuane would ever have made headway in becoming his counselor.

wɛl, nɪneɪiv wɑzn əbaʊt tə æk ðə seɪm weɪ fəɹ ɹænd ælθɹ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni fænsi taɪɾəlz i hæd. haʊɛvɝ, ʃi dɪɾ əv sʌmθɪŋ tə lɝn fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪnz səksɛs. pɝhæps ɹænd hæd lɪsən tə mɔɪɹeɪn kəz əɹ səbsɝviəns hæd flæɾɝd hɪm, əɹ meɪbi hi hæd sɪmpli bɪn taɪɝɾ ə pipəl pʊʃɪŋ ɪm ɝaʊnd. ɹænd dɪɾ əv mɛni pipəl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl hɪm. ðeɪ mʌs fɹʌstʃɹeɪt hɪm, ən ðeɪ meɪd nɪneɪivz oʊn dʒɑb ə lɑt mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt, sɪns ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn ðəɾ i æktʃəli  niɾəd tə lɪsən tə.

Well, Nynaeve wasn't about to act the same way for Rand al'Thor, no matter how many fancy titles he had. However, she did have something to learn from Moiraine's success. Perhaps Rand had listened to Moiraine because her subservience had flattered him, or maybe he had simply been tired of people pushing him around. Rand did have many people trying to control him. They must frustrate him, and they made Nynaeve's own job a lot more difficult, since she was the one that he actually needed to listen to.

dɪd hi, pɝhæps, si hɝ sɪmpli əz ənʌðɝ ə ðoʊz ɪɹɛləvən mənɪpjəleɪɾɝz? ʃi wʊdn pʊɾ ɪt pæs hɪm.

Did he, perhaps, see her simply as another of those irrelevant manipulators? She wouldn't put it past him.

ʃi niɾəd tə ʃoʊ hɪm ðət ðeɪ wɝ wɝkɪŋ fəɹ ðə seɪm ɡoʊlz. ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə tɛl ɪm wʌt tə du; ʃi dʒʌst wɑntəɾ ɪm tə stɑp æktɪŋ laɪk ə ful. ænd, bɪɑn ðæt, ʃi dʒʌst wɑntəɾ ɪm tə bi seɪf. ʃiɾ ɔlsoʊ laɪk ɪm tə bi ə liɾɝ ðət pipəl ɹɪspɛktɪd, nɑt wʌn ðət pipəl fɪɹd. hi simd ɪnkeɪpəbəl ə siɪŋ ðət ðə pæθ i wɑz ɑn wɑz ðəɾ ʌv ə taɪɹənt.

She needed to show him that they were working for the same goals. She didn't want to tell him what to do; she just wanted him to stop acting like a fool. And, beyond that, she just wanted him to be safe. She'd also like him to be a leader that people respected, not one that people feared. He seemed incapable of seeing that the path he was on was that of a tyrant.

biɪŋ ə kɪŋ ɹɪli wɑzn ɔl ðət dɪfɹən fɹəm biɪŋ meɪɝ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ðə meɪɝ niɾəd tə bi ɹɪspɛktɪɾ ən laɪkt. ðə wɪzdəm ən ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl kəd də ðə dɪfəkəl tæsks, sətʃ əz pʌnɪʃɪŋ ðoʊz u oʊvɝstɛp ðɛɹ baʊnz. ðə meɪɝ, haʊɛvɝ, niɾəd tə bi lʌvd.

Being a king really wasn't all that different from being mayor in the Two Rivers. The mayor needed to be respected and liked. The Wisdom and the Women's Circle could do the difficult tasks, such as punishing those who overstepped their bounds. The mayor, however, needed to be loved.

ðət lɛd tə ə sɪvəl ən ə seɪf taʊn.

That led to a civil and a safe town.

bʌt haʊ tə ʃoʊ ðət tə ɹænd? ʃi kʊdn fɔɹs hɪm; ʃi niɾəd tə ɡɛɾ ɪm tə lɪsən tə hɝ ɪn ənʌðɝ weɪ. ə plæn bɪɡæn tə teɪk ɹuɾ ɪn əɹ hɛd. baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi ɹitʃt ðə mænʃən, ʃi hæɾ ən aɪdiə ʌv wʌt tə du.

But how to show that to Rand? She couldn't force him; she needed to get him to listen to her in another way. A plan began to take root in her head. By the time she reached the mansion, she had an idea of what to do.

ðə ɡeɪt tə ðə mænʃən ɡɹaʊnz wɑz ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ sɑldəiənz; ði il pɹəfɝd tə steɪ kloʊsɝ tə ɹænd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə ɹumz ən ðə hɔlweɪz ə ðə mænʃən ɪtsɛlf. heɪstɝ nælmæt, ði ɔfəsɝ ɑn duɾi, ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ə baʊ əz ʃi əpɹoʊtʃt; səm pipəl stɪl nu haʊ tə tʃɹiɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə ɡɹaʊnz bɪɑn ðə ɡeɪt wɝ ɔɹnəmɛntəl ən kʌltəveɪɾəd. nɪneɪivz læntɝn kæst stʃɹeɪnʒ ʃædoʊz ɑn ðə ɡɹæs əz ɪts laɪt ʃoʊn θɹu ðə tʃɹiz tʃɹeɪn ən tʃɹɪmd ɪn ðə ʃeɪps ə fænsɪfəl ænəməlz. ðə ʃædoʊz muvd ɪn kɑnsɝt wɪð əɹ læntɝn, ðə fæntəm ʃeɪps lɛŋθənɪŋ ən mɝdʒɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ blæknəs ə ðə naɪɾ ɝaʊn hɝ. laɪk ɹɪvɝz ə ʃædoʊ.

The gate to the mansion grounds was guarded by Saldaeans; the Aiel preferred to stay closer to Rand, watching the rooms and the hallways of the mansion itself. Haster Nalmat, the officer on duty, gave Nynaeve a bow as she approached; some people still knew how to treat Aes Sedai. The grounds beyond the gate were ornamental and cultivated. Nynaeve's lantern cast strange shadows on the grass as its light shone through the trees trained and trimmed in the shapes of fanciful animals. The shadows moved in concert with her lantern, the phantom shapes lengthening and merging with the greater blackness of the night around her. Like rivers of shadow.

ə lɑɹdʒɝ ɡɹup ə sɑldəiən soʊlʒɝz stʊd ɡɑɹɾ ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə mænʃən; fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən wɝ nɛsəsɛɹi. wɛnɛvɝ mɛn stʊɾ ɑn ɡɑɹd, ðɛɹ fɹɛnz tɛndəd tə ɡæðɝ, noʊ daʊt tə ɡɑsəp. nɪneɪiv stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ðə ɡɹup, kɑzɪŋ sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm tə stɑp linɪŋ læzəli əɡɛns ðə mænʃənz ɡælɝi ʌv pɪlɝz.

A larger group of Saldaean soldiers stood guard at the front of the mansion; far more than were necessary. Whenever men stood on guard, their friends tended to gather, no doubt to gossip. Nynaeve strode up to the group, causing several of them to stop leaning lazily against the mansion's gallery of pillars.

"hu ʌv jə ɑɹ nɑɾ ɑn duɾi ɹaɪt naʊ?" ʃi æskt.

"Who of you are not on duty right now?" she asked.

ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, θɹi ʌv ðə naɪn soʊlʒɝz ɹeɪz ðɛɹ hænz, lʊkɪŋ sʌmwʌt ʃipɪʃ.

Sure enough, three of the nine soldiers raised their hands, looking somewhat sheepish.

"ɛksələnt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, hændɪŋ əɹ læntɝn tə wʌn ə ðɛm. "ju θɹi, kʌm wɪð mi." ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə mænʃən, ðə θɹi soʊlʒɝz skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɪn bɪhaɪnd.

"Excellent," Nynaeve said, handing her lantern to one of them. "You three, come with me." She strode into the mansion, the three soldiers scrambling in behind.

ɪt wɑz leɪt - ðə ɡoʊs pɹəsɛʃən əpɪɹɾ oʊnli ət mɪdnaɪt - ən ðə mænʃən slʌmbɝd. ði ɪntʃɹəkət ʃændəlɪɹ ɪn ði ɛntʃɹɪweɪ hæd bɪn ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃt, ən ðə hɔlweɪz wɝ dɑɹk. tɛstɪŋ əɹ mɛmɹi, ʃi pɪkt ə dɝɛkʃən ən wɔk daʊn ɪt. ðə waɪtwɑʃt wɔlz wɝ əz ɪmækjulɪt hɪɹ əz ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ʌðɝ sɛkʃənz ə ðə mænʃən, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ənɔɹnəmɛntɪd. hɝ ɪnstɪŋk pɹuv kɝɛkt əz ʃi sun ɛntɝɾ ə smɔl pæntʃɹi, wɛɹ sɝvəns wəd pɹipɛɹ plæɾɝz ə fud bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ əm tə ðə daɪnɪŋ ɹum. ðə hɔlweɪ ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən lɛɾ aʊt tə ðə mænʃən sɪɾɪŋ ɹumz;

It was late - the ghost procession appeared only at midnight - and the mansion slumbered. The intricate chandelier in the entryway had been extinguished, and the hallways were dark. Testing her memory, she picked a direction and walked down it. The whitewashed walls were as immaculate here as they were in other sections of the mansion, but they were unornamented. Her instinct proved correct as she soon entered a small pantry, where servants would prepare platters of food before taking them to the dining room. The hallway she had chosen led out to the mansion sitting rooms;

ənʌðɝ hɔlweɪ ət ðə bæk lɛd tə ðə kɪtʃənz. ðə ɹum wɑz fɝnɪʃt wɪð ə bɪɡ stɝɾi wʊɾən teɪbəl ən səm tɔl stulz. ðoʊz wɝ ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ ə ɡɹup ə mɛn pleɪɪŋ ə ɡeɪm ə daɪs, wɛɹɪŋ ɡɹin ən waɪt lɪnən ʃɝts - ðə lɪvɝi ʌv maɪləsɹz haʊs - wɪð θɪk wɝk tʃɹaʊzɝz.

another hallway at the back led to the kitchens. The room was furnished with a big sturdy wooden table and some tall stools. Those were occupied by a group of men playing a game of dice, wearing green and white linen shirts - the livery of Milisair's house - with thick work trousers.

ðeɪ lʊkt ʌp wɪð ʃɑk əz nɪneɪiv stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum; wʌn ə ðə mɛn æktʃəli  lɛp tə hɪz fit, hɪz stul tɑpəlɪŋ tə ðə flɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi pʊld ɔf ɪz hæt - ə lɑpsaɪɾɪd bɹaʊn θɪŋ ðəɾ ivən wʊɾə əv bɪn ɪmbɛɹəs tə wɛɹ - lʊkɪŋ laɪk ə tʃaɪl kɑt poʊkɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝ ɪndə ðə paɪ bɪfɔɹ dɪnɝ.

They looked up with shock as Nynaeve strode into the room; one of the men actually leaped to his feet, his stool toppling to the floor behind him. He pulled off his hat - a lopsided brown thing that even Mat would have been embarrassed to wear - looking like a child caught poking his finger into the pie before dinner.

nɪneɪiv dɪdn kɛɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ; ʃi hæd faʊn səm sɝvəns ə ðə mænʃən, ən ðət wɑz ɔl ðət mæɾɝd. "aɪ mʌst si ðə doʊsən," ʃi sɛd, juzɪŋ ðə loʊkəl tɝm fəɹ ðə hɛd haʊskipɝ.

Nynaeve didn't care what they were doing; she had found some servants of the mansion, and that was all that mattered. "I must see the dosun," she said, using the local term for the head housekeeper.

"fɛtʃ əɹ fəɹ mi."

"Fetch her for me."

hɝ soʊlʒɝz ɛntɝd ðə ɹum bɪhaɪn hɝ. ɔl θɹi wɝ sɑldəiənz, ən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ sʌmwʌɾ ɑæfɪʃ, ðeɪ wɔkt wɪð ðə swæɝz ə mɛn u ɪntəmətli ʌndɝstʊd faɪɾɪŋ. ʃi daʊɾɪd ðət ðiz sɪmpəl sɝvəns niɾəd ɛni mɔɹ ɪntɪmɪdeɪʃən ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðə soʊlʒɝz wəd laɪkli pɹuv jusfəl leɪɾɝ.

Her soldiers entered the room behind her. All three were Saldaeans, and if they were somewhat oafish, they walked with the swaggers of men who intimately understood fighting. She doubted that these simple servants needed any more intimidation than an Aes Sedai, but the soldiers would likely prove useful later.

"ðə doʊsən?" ðə wɝkɝ wɪð ðə hæt faɪnəli sɛd. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə wʊdn ɹæðɝ si ðə stuɝɾ əɹ - "

"The dosun?" the worker with the hat finally said. "Are you sure you wouldn't rather see the steward or - "

"ðə doʊsən," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "bɹɪŋ əɹ tə mi naʊ. ɡɪv əɹ taɪm tə θɹoʊ ɑn ə ɹoʊb, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ." ʃi pɔɪntəɾ ət wʌn ə hɝ soʊlʒɝz. "ju, ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm. meɪk ʃʊɹ i dʌzn spik tə ɛniwʌn ɛls əɹ ɡɪv ðə wʊmən ə tʃæns tə ɪskeɪp."

"The dosun," Nynaeve said. "Bring her to me now. Give her time to throw on a robe, but no more." She pointed at one of her soldiers. "You, go with him. Make sure he doesn't speak to anyone else or give the woman a chance to escape."

"ɪskeɪp?" ðə wɝkɝ jɛlpt. "waɪ wəd lɔɹəl wɑnə də ðæt? wʌd ʃi du, maɪ leɪɾi?"

"Escape?" the worker yelped. "Why would Loral want to do that? What did she do, my Lady?"

"nʌθɪŋ, aɪ hoʊp. ɡoʊ!"

"Nothing, I hope. Go!"

ðə tu mɛn - wʌn wɝkɝ, wʌn soʊlʒɝ - hɝiɾ ɔf, ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi wɝkɝz ɹɪmeɪn ət ðə teɪbəl, lʊkɪŋ ənkʌmftəɹbəl. nɪneɪiv foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ əɹ plæn.

The two men - one worker, one soldier - hurried off, and the other three workers remained at the table, looking uncomfortable. Nynaeve folded her arms beneath her breasts, considering her plan.

ɹænd hæd dɪtɝmən ðəɾ ɪz hʌn fəɹ ðə dəmɑni kɪŋ hæd hɪɾ ə wɔl wɪð ðə dɛθ ə ðə mɛsənʒɝ.

Rand had determined that his hunt for the Domani king had hit a wall with the death of the messenger.

nɪneɪiv wɑzn soʊ sɝɾən. ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz ɪnvɑlvd, ən ə fju wɛl-pleɪs kwɛstʃənz maɪt bi vɛɹi ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ.

Nynaeve wasn't so certain. There were others involved, and a few well-placed questions might be very illuminating.

ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðə doʊsən hæd dʌn ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. bʌt nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt wɑn ðə wɝkɝ u fɛtʃt əɹ lɛɾɪŋ ɪz tʌŋ wæɡ tə ðə pipəl i maɪt miɾ əlɔŋ ðə weɪ; bɛɾɝ tə ɪnstɪl ɪndə hɪm ə sɛns ə deɪnʒɝ ən juz ðə soʊlʒɝ tə kip ɪm kwaɪət. nɑt tə mɛnʃən pʌŋktʃuəl.

It was unlikely the dosun had done anything wrong. But Nynaeve did not want the worker who fetched her letting his tongue wag to the people he might meet along the way; better to instill into him a sense of danger and use the soldier to keep him quiet. Not to mention punctual.

hɝ fɔɹsaɪt pɹuvd ɪfɛktɪv. wɪðɪn mɪnəts, ðə wɝkɝ hɝid bæk ɪndə ðə ɹum, toʊɪŋ ə dɪʃɛvəld, ɛldɝli wʊmən ɪn ə blu ivnɪŋ ɹoʊb. ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ poʊkt aʊt fɹəm bɪniθ əɹ heɪstəli ɹæpt ɹɛd kɝtʃəf, ən əɹ eɪdʒɪŋ dəmɑni feɪs wɑz æbsəlutli waɪt wɪð æpɹɪhɛnʃən. nɪneɪiv fɛlt ɡɪlti. haʊ ðɪs wʊmən mʌs fil, ɔfoʊkən ət naɪt baɪ ə tɛɹəfaɪd sɝvən kleɪmɪŋ ðət wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑntəɾ əɹ ɪmiɾiətli!

Her foresight proved effective. Within minutes, the worker hurried back into the room, towing a disheveled, elderly woman in a blue evening robe. Gray hair poked out from beneath her hastily wrapped red kerchief, and her aging Domani face was absolutely white with apprehension. Nynaeve felt guilty. How this woman must feel, awoken at night by a terrified servant claiming that one of the Aes Sedai wanted her immediately!

ðə sɑldəiən soʊlʒɝ fɑloʊd, ðən stʊd ɡɑɹd bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹweɪ. hi wɑz boʊlɪɡd ən skwɑt, ən i wɔɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz lɔŋ sɑldəiən mʌstæʃɪz. ði ʌðɝ tu laʊnʒd bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹweɪ nɪneɪiv hæd kʌm θɹu, ðɛɹ kæʒəwəl ɛɹ oʊnli sɝvɪŋ tə meɪk ðə ɹum mɔɹ tɛns. ðeɪ hæd pɪkt ʌp ɑn sʌmθɪŋ ə hɝ ɪntɛnt, ɪt simd.

The Saldaean soldier followed, then stood guard beside the doorway. He was bowlegged and squat, and he wore one of those long Saldaean mustaches. The other two lounged beside the doorway Nynaeve had come through, their casual air only serving to make the room more tense. They had picked up on something of her intent, it seemed.

"pis, ɡʊdwʊmən," nɪneɪiv sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə teɪbəl. "ju meɪ sɪt. jə ʌðɝz, ɡoʊ tə ðə meɪn ɛntʃɹɪweɪ ən steɪ ðɛɹ. doʊn spik tə ɛniwʌn."

"Peace, goodwoman," Nynaeve said, nodding to the table. "You may sit. You others, go to the main entryway and stay there. Don't speak to anyone."

ðə fɔɹ wɝkɝz niɾəd noʊ fɝðɝ pɹɑɾɪŋ. nɪneɪiv toʊld wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz tə fɑloʊ ðɛm ən meɪk sɝɾən ðeɪ dɪɾ əz ʃi sɛd. ðə leɪɾ aʊɝ wɑz wɝkɪŋ tə hɝ ædvæntɪdʒ; wɪð soʊ mɛni ʌv ðə sɝvəns ən ɹændz ətɛndəns əslip, ʃi kəɾ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt wɪθaʊɾ əlɝɾɪŋ ðoʊz u maɪt bi ɡɪlti.

The four workers needed no further prodding. Nynaeve told one of the soldiers to follow them and make certain they did as she said. The late hour was working to her advantage; with so many of the servants and Rand's attendants asleep, she could investigate without alerting those who might be guilty.

ðə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ə ðə wɝkɝz oʊnli meɪd ðə doʊsən mɔɹ nɝvəs. nɪneɪiv sæɾ ət ðə teɪbəl ɑn wʌn ə ðə veɪkeɪɾəd stulz. ðə mɛn hæd lɛf ðɛɹ daɪs bɪhaɪn ɪn ðɛɹ heɪst, bʌt hæd - ʌv kɔɹs - meɪd ʃʊɹ tə teɪk ðɛɹ kɔɪnz. ðə ɹum wɑz lɪt baɪ ə smɔl læmp, bɝnɪŋ wɪð ən oʊpən fleɪm ɑn ðə wɪndaʊsəl. ðə sɑldəiən hæd teɪkən əɹ læntɝn wɪð ɪm wən fɑloʊɪŋ ðə wɝkɝz.

The departure of the workers only made the dosun more nervous. Nynaeve sat at the table on one of the vacated stools. The men had left their dice behind in their haste, but had - of course - made sure to take their coins. The room was lit by a small lamp, burning with an open flame on the windowsill. The Saldaean had taken her lantern with him when following the workers.

"jɔɹ neɪm ɪz lɔɹəl, ɪz ɪt nɑt?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"Your name is Loral, is it not?" Nynaeve asked.

ðə doʊsən nɑɾəd wɛɹəli.

The dosun nodded warily.

"ju ɑɹ əwɛɹ ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ də nɑt laɪ?"

"You are aware that Aes Sedai do not lie?"

ðə haʊskipɝ nɑɾəd əɡɛn. moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ kʊdn laɪ, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv tɛknɪkəli kʊd, sɪns ʃi hædn hɛl ði oʊθ ɹɑd. ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌɾ ɝn əɹ ə lɛsɝ stæɾəs ɪn ði aɪz ə ði ʌðɝz. ʌndɪzɝvədli soʊ. ði oʊθ ɹɑd wɑz oʊnli ə fɔɹmæləɾi; tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk niɾəd noʊ tɛɹæŋɡɹil tə meɪk əm ɑnəst. "ðɛn jəl bɪliv mi wən aɪ tɛl jə ðəɾ aɪ də nɑt səspɛk jə pɝsənəli ʌv hævɪŋ dʌn ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. aɪ dʒʌs nid jəɹ hɛlp."

The housekeeper nodded again. Most Aes Sedai couldn't lie, though Nynaeve technically could, since she hadn't held the Oath Rod. That was part of what earned her a lesser status in the eyes of the others. Undeservedly so. The Oath Rod was only a formality; Two Rivers folk needed no ter'angreal to make them honest. "Then you will believe me when I tell you that I do not suspect you personally of having done anything wrong. I just need your help."

ðə wʊmən sim tə ɹɪlæks ə bɪt. "wʌt hɛlp dʒju nid, nɪneɪiv sədaɪ?"

The woman seemed to relax a bit. "What help do you need, Nynaeve Sedai?"

"ɪɾ əz bɪn maɪ ɪkspɪɹiəns ðət ðə hɛd haʊskipɝ noʊz mɔɹ ʌv ə haʊsəz wɝkɪŋz ðən ðə stuɝdz, əɹ ivən ði oʊnɝz ə ðə pɹɑpɝɾi. hæv jə bɪn ɛmplɔɪd hɪɹ fəɹ lɔŋ?"

"It has been my experience that the head housekeeper knows more of a house's workings than the stewards, or even the owners of the property. Have you been employed here for long?"

"aɪ hæv sɝv ðə tʃædmɑɝ fæmli θɹu θɹi dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz," ði oʊld wʊmən sɛd wɪð noʊ smɔl mɛʒɝ ə pɹaɪd. "æn hæd hoʊp tə sɝv ənʌðɝ, ɪf əɹ leɪdɪʃɪp hæd - " ðə haʊskipɝ kʌɾ ɔf.

"I have served the Chadmar family through three generations," the old woman said with no small measure of pride. "And had hoped to serve another, if Her Ladyship had - " The housekeeper cut off.

ɹænd hæɾ ɪmpɹɪzənd "hɝ leɪdɪʃɪp" ɪn əɹ oʊn dʌnʒənz. ðət dɪdn boʊd wɛl fəɹ ðəɹ biɪŋ ənʌðɝ dʒɛnɝeɪʃən tə sɝv.

Rand had imprisoned "Her Ladyship" in her own dungeons. That didn't bode well for there being another generation to serve.

"jɛs, wɛl," nɪneɪiv sɛd, kʌvɝɪŋ ði ənkʌmftəɹbəl saɪləns. "ði ənfɔɹtʃənət sɝkəmstænsəz ɪnvɑlvɪŋ jəɹ leɪɾi ɑɹ pɑɹɾ ə maɪ tæsk ðɪs ivnɪŋ."

"Yes, well," Nynaeve said, covering the uncomfortable silence. "The unfortunate circumstances involving your lady are part of my task this evening."

"nɪneɪiv sədaɪ," ði eɪdʒɪd wʊmən sɛd, ɡɹoʊɪŋ iɡɝ, "du jə səpoʊz jə kən si hɝ tə fɹiɾəm? ɹɪstɔɹ əɹ tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡənz ɡʊd ɡɹeɪsɪz?"

"Nynaeve Sedai," the aged woman said, growing eager, "do you suppose you can see her to freedom? Restore her to the Lord Dragon's good graces?"

"pɝhæps." daʊtfəl, nɪneɪiv æɾəd ɪn əɹ maɪnd, bʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪz pɑsəbəl. "maɪ æktɪvəɾiz tənaɪt meɪ hɛlp. dɪd jə ɛvɝ si ðɪs mɛsənʒɝ, ðə wʌn jəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ɪmpɹɪzənd?"

"Perhaps." Doubtful, Nynaeve added in her mind, but anything is possible. "My activities tonight may help. Did you ever see this messenger, the one your mistress imprisoned?"

"ðə wʌn sɛn baɪ ðə kɪŋ?" lɔɹəl æskt. "aɪ nɛvɝ spoʊk wɪð hɪm, ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd si hɪm.

"The one sent by the King?" Loral asked. "I never spoke with him, Aes Sedai, but I did see him.

tɔl, hænsəm fɛloʊ, kjʊɹiəsli klin-ʃeɪvən fəɹ ə dəmɑni mæn. aɪ pæst ɪm ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. hæd wʌn ə ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl feɪsəz aɪ ɹaɪtli θɪŋk aɪv ɛvɝ sin ɑn ə mæn."

Tall, handsome fellow, curiously clean-shaven for a Domani man. I passed him in the hallway. Had one of the most beautiful faces I rightly think I've ever seen on a man."

"æn ðɛn?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"And then?" Nynaeve asked.

"wɛl, hi wɛn dɝɛkli tə spik wɪð leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝ, ən ðɛn. . . ." lɔɹəl tʃɹeɪld ɔf. "nɪneɪiv sədaɪ, aɪ doʊn min tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ maɪ leɪɾi ɪndə ɛni mɔɹ tʃɹʌbəl, ən - "

"Well, he went directly to speak with Lady Chadmar, and then. . . ." Loral trailed off. "Nynaeve Sedai, I don't mean to be getting my lady into any more trouble, and - "

"hi wɑz sɛn fəɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɔɹtli. "aɪ hæv lɪɾəl taɪm fəɹ fulɪʃnəs, lɔɹəl. aɪm nɑt hɪɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɛvəɾəns əɡɛns jəɹ mɪstʃɹəs, ən aɪ doʊn ɹɪli kɛɹ wʌt jəɹ lɔɪəltiz ɑɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ɪʃuz ət steɪk. ænsɝ maɪ kwɛstʃən."

"He was sent for questioning," Nynaeve said shortly. "I have little time for foolishness, Loral. I am not here looking for evidence against your mistress, and I don't really care what your loyalties are. There are much larger issues at stake. Answer my question."

"jɛs, leɪɾi," lɔɹəl sɛd, pælɪŋ. "wi ɔl nu wʌt hæd hæpənd, ʌv kɔɹs. dɪdn sim ɹaɪt, sɛndɪŋ wʌn ə ðə kɪŋz mɛn tə ə kwɛstʃənɝ laɪk ðæt. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðət mæn. ʃeɪm tə mɑɹ ə feɪs soʊ bjuɾəfəl, ən ɔl."

"Yes, Lady," Loral said, paling. "We all knew what had happened, of course. Didn't seem right, sending one of the King's men to a questioner like that. Particularly that man. Shame to mar a face so beautiful, and all."

"ju noʊ ðə loʊkeɪʃən ə ðə kwɛstʃənɝ ən ðə dʌnʒən?"

"You know the location of the questioner and the dungeon?"

lɔɹəl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli. ɡʊd. ʃi dɪdn ɪntɛn tə wɪθhoʊld ɪnfɝmeɪʃən.

Loral hesitated, then nodded reluctantly. Good. She didn't intend to withhold information.

"lɛɾ əs ɡoʊ, ðɛn," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ.

"Let us go, then," Nynaeve said, rising.

"maɪ leɪɾi?"

"My Lady?"

"tə ðə dʌnʒən," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ əsum ɪɾ ɪzən ɑn ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ɛniwɛɹ, nɑɾ ɪf maɪləsɹ tʃædmɑɝ wɑz əz kɛɹfəl əz aɪ θɪŋk."

"To the dungeon," Nynaeve said. "I assume it isn't on the property anywhere, not if Milisair Chadmar was as careful as I think."

"ɪts ə mɑɾəst dɪstəns əweɪ, ɪn ðə ɡʌlz fist," lɔɹəl sɛd. "ju wɪʃ tə ɡoʊ tənaɪt?"

"It's a modest distance away, in the Gull's Feast," Loral said. "You wish to go tonight?"

"jɛs," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ənlɛs aɪ dɪsaɪd tə vɪzət ðə kwɛstʃənɝ əɾ ɪz hoʊm ɪnstɛd."

"Yes," Nynaeve said, then hesitated. "Unless I decide to visit the questioner at his home instead."

"ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə seɪm pleɪs, maɪ leɪɾi."

"They are the same place, my Lady."

"ɛksələnt. kʌm."

"Excellent. Come."

lɔɹəl dɪdn əv mʌtʃ tʃɔɪs. nɪneɪiv əlaʊɾ əɹ - ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ ə soʊlʒɝ - tə ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ ɹumz fəɹ ə dʒɹɛs.

Loral didn't have much choice. Nynaeve allowed her - guarded by a soldier - to return to her rooms for a dress.

ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ, nɪneɪiv ən əɹ soʊlʒɝz mɑɹtʃt ðə doʊsən - əlɔŋ wɪð ðə fɔɹ wɝkɝz, tə kip əm fɹəm æksədɛntəli ɡɪvɪŋ wɔɹnɪŋ ʌv wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ - fɹəm ðə bɪldɪŋ. ɔl faɪv lʊk dɪsaɪɾədli dɪsplizd. ðeɪ pɹɑbli bɪliv ðə supɝstɪʃəs ɹumɝz ðət ðə naɪt wɑz nɑt seɪf. nɪneɪiv nu bɛɾɝ. ðə naɪt maɪt nɑt bi seɪf, bʌɾ ɪt wɑzn ɛni wɝs ðən ʌðɝ taɪmz. ɪn fækt, ɪt maɪt bi seɪfɝ. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ pipəl əbaʊt, ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ tʃænsəz ə sʌmwʌn nɪɹbaɪ sʌɾənli ɡɹoʊɪŋ θɔɹnz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ skɪn, bɝstɪŋ ɪndə fleɪm əɹ daɪɪŋ ɪn səm ʌðɝ hɔɹəbli ɹændəm weɪ.

A short time later, Nynaeve and her soldiers marched the dosun - along with the four workers, to keep them from accidentally giving warning of what was happening - from the building. All five looked decidedly displeased. They probably believed the superstitious rumors that the night was not safe. Nynaeve knew better. The night might not be safe, but it wasn't any worse than other times. In fact, it might be safer. If there were fewer people about, there were fewer chances of someone nearby suddenly growing thorns out of their skin, bursting into flame or dying in some other horribly random way.

ðeɪ lɛf ðə mænʃən ɡɹaʊnz, nɪneɪiv wɔkɪŋ wɪð ə fɝm stɛp, hoʊpɪŋ tə kip ði ʌðɝz fɹəm filɪŋ tu nɝvəs. ʃi nɑɾəd tə ðə soʊlʒɝz ət ðə ɡeɪt, ən wɛn ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən lɔɹəl ɪndəkeɪɾəd.

They left the mansion grounds, Nynaeve walking with a firm step, hoping to keep the others from feeling too nervous. She nodded to the soldiers at the gate, and went in the direction Loral indicated.

ðɛɹ fit θʌmpt əɡɛns ðə wʊɾ ə ðə bɔɹdwɔk, ðə klaʊɾəd naɪt skaɪ ɡloʊɪŋ dʒʌs feɪnli fɹəm munlaɪɾ əbʌv.

Their feet thumped against the wood of the boardwalk, the clouded night sky glowing just faintly from moonlight above.

nɪneɪiv dɪdnt ɡɪv hɝsɛlf ðə lʌɡʒɝi ʌv kwɛstʃənɪŋ əɹ plæn. ʃid dɪsaɪɾɪd ɑn ə kɔɹs, ən soʊ fɑɹ ɪt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ wɛl. tʃɹu, ɹænd maɪt ɡɹoʊ æŋɡɹi əɾ əɹ fəɹ əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝz ən stɝɪŋ ʌp tʃɹʌbəl. bʌt səmtaɪmz, tə si wʌt wɑz ət ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə klaʊɾi ɹeɪn bæɹəl, jə niɾəd tə stɝ ðə wɔɾɝ tə bɹɪŋ ʌp wʌt wɑz ət ðə bɑɾəm. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs tu koʊɪnsədɛntəl. maɪləsɹ tʃædmɑɝ hæd teɪkən ðə mɛsənʒɝ kæptɪv mʌnθs əɡoʊ, bʌɾ i hæd daɪɾ oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt taɪm bɪfɔɹ ɹænd wɑntəd hɪm. hi wɑz ði oʊnli pɝsən ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɪð ə klu tə ðə kɪŋz loʊkeɪʃən.

Nynaeve didn't give herself the luxury of questioning her plan. She'd decided on a course, and so far it was going well. True, Rand might grow angry at her for appropriating soldiers and stirring up trouble. But sometimes, to see what was at the bottom of a cloudy rain barrel, you needed to stir the water to bring up what was at the bottom. It was just too coincidental. Milisair Chadmar had taken the messenger captive months ago, but he had died only a short time before Rand wanted him. He was the only person in the city with a clue to the King's location.

koʊɪnsəɾənsɪz dɪd hæpən. səmtaɪmz, wən tu fɑɹmɝz wɝ fjuɾɪŋ ən wʌn ə ðɛɹ kaʊz daɪɾ ɪn ðə naɪt, ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ən æksəɾənt. ən səmtaɪmz, ə lɪɾəl sɝtʃɪŋ ənkʌvɝd ði ɑpəzət.

Coincidences did happen. Sometimes, when two farmers were feuding and one of their cows died in the night, it was just an accident. And sometimes, a little searching uncovered the opposite.

lɔɹəl lɛd ðə ɡɹup təwɔɹd ðə ɡʌlz fist, ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə ɡʌl dɪstʃɹɪkt, ə pɑɹɾ ə taʊn kloʊs tə wɛɹ ðə fɪʃɝmɪn dʌmpt weɪs fɹəm ðɛɹ hɔlz. laɪk moʊst sɛnsəbəl pipəl, nɪneɪiv əvɔɪɾəd ðət sɛkʃən ə taʊn, ən əɹ noʊz ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ dʒʌst waɪ əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt. fɪʃ ɡʌts maɪt meɪk ɛksələn fɝɾəlaɪzɝ, bʌt nɪneɪiv kəd smɛl ðə kɑmpoʊstɪŋ hips fɹəm sɛvɹəl stʃɹits əweɪ. ivən ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz əvɔɪɾəd ðɪs dɑɹk ɛɹiə.

Loral led the group toward the Gull's Feast, also known as the Gull District, a part of town close to where the fishermen dumped waste from their hauls. Like most sensible people, Nynaeve avoided that section of town, and her nose reminded her just why as they approached. Fish guts might make excellent fertilizer, but Nynaeve could smell the composting heaps from several streets away. Even the refugees avoided this dark area.

ðə wɔk wɑz ə fɛɹli lɔŋ wʌn - ʌndɝstændəbli, ðə ɹɪtʃ sɛktɝ ə taʊn wɑz dɪstən fɹəm ðə ɡʌlz fist. nɪneɪiv stɔkt əlɔŋ, peɪɪŋ noʊ hid tə ðə ʃæɾoʊd æliweɪz ən bɪldɪŋz, ðoʊ hɝ ɑntʊɹɑʒ - soʊlʒɝz ɪksɛptɪd - klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊn əɹ əpɹɪhɛnsɪvli. ðə sɑldəiənz ɪnstɛd kɛp ðɛɹ hænz ɑn ðɛɹ sɝpəntaɪn sɔɹdz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz ət wʌns.

The walk was a fairly long one - understandably, the rich sector of town was distant from the Gull's Feast. Nynaeve stalked along, paying no heed to the shadowed alleyways and buildings, though her entourage - soldiers excepted - clustered around her apprehensively. The Saldaeans instead kept their hands on their serpentine swords, trying to look in all directions at once.

ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd nuz fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ. haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ ɪt bɪn sɪns ʃid hæd nuz fɹəm ɛɡwin əɹ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz? ʃi fɛl blaɪnd. ɪt wɑz əɹ oʊn fɔl fəɹ ɪnsɪstɪŋ ðət ʃi ɡoʊ wɪð ɹænd. sʌmwʌn hæd niɾəd tə kip ən aɪ ɑn hɪm, bʌt ðət mɛn biɪŋ əneɪbəl tə kip ɛni aɪz ɑn ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. wɑz ðə taʊɝ stɪl dɪvaɪɾəd? wɑz ɛɡwin stɪl æmɪɝlɪn? nuz ɑn ðə stʃɹits wɑz lɪɾəl hɛlp. əz ɔlweɪz, fəɹ ɛvɹi ɹumɝ ʃi hɝd, ðəɹ wɝ tu mɔɹ kɑntʃɹədɪktɪŋ ɪt. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz faɪɾɪŋ ɪtsɛlf. noʊ, ɪt fɔt ði æʃəmən. noʊ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn. əɹ baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. noʊ, ðoʊz ɹumɝz wɝ ɔl laɪz spɹɛd baɪ ðə taʊɝ tə beɪɾ ɪts ɛnəmiz ɪndə stʃɹaɪkɪŋ.

She wished she had news from the White Tower. How long had it been since she'd had news from Egwene or one of the others? She felt blind. It was her own fault for insisting that she go with Rand. Someone had needed to keep an eye on him, but that meant being unable to keep any eyes on everyone else. Was the Tower still divided? Was Egwene still Amyrlin? News on the streets was little help. As always, for every rumor she heard, there were two more contradicting it. The White Tower was fighting itself. No, it fought the Asha'man. No, the Aes Sedai had been destroyed by the Seanchan. Or by the Dragon Reborn. No, those rumors were all lies spread by the Tower to bait its enemies into striking.

vɛɹi lɪɾəl wɑz sɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪleɪɾə əɹ ɛɡwin spəsɪfɪkli, ðoʊ ɡɑɹbəl nuz ə tu æmɪɝlənz wɑz spɹɛɾɪŋ. ðət wɑz pɹɑbləmæɾɪk. niðɝ ɡɹup ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd laɪk spɹɛɾɪŋ ðə nuz ʌv ə sɛkən æmɪɝlɪn. teɪlz ə skwɑbəlz əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ oʊnli ɛn ʌp hɝɾɪŋ ɔl ə ðɛm.

Very little was said about Elaida or Egwene specifically, though garbled news of two Amyrlins was spreading. That was problematic. Neither group of Aes Sedai would like spreading the news of a second Amyrlin. Tales of squabbles among the Aes Sedai would only end up hurting all of them.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli, lɔɹəl stɑpt wɔkɪŋ. ðə fɔɹ wɝkɝz stɑp bɪhaɪn hɝ, bʌndəlɪŋ təɡɛðɝ wɪð wɝiɾ ɪkspɹɛʃənz. nɪneɪiv ɡlænst ət lɔɹəl. "wɛl?"

Eventually, Loral stopped walking. The four workers stopped behind her, bundling together with worried expressions. Nynaeve glanced at Loral. "Well?"

"ðɛɹ, leɪɾi." ðə wʊmən pɔɪntəɾ ə boʊni fɪŋɡɝ tə ðə bɪldɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit.

"There, Lady." The woman pointed a bony finger to the building across the street.

"ðə tʃænlɝz ʃɑp?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"The chandler's shop?" Nynaeve asked.

lɔɹəl nɑɾəd.

Loral nodded.

nɪneɪiv sʌmənd wʌn ə ðə boʊlɪɡd sɑldəiən soʊlʒɝz. "ju, wɑtʃ ðiz faɪv ən meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ doʊnt ɡɛɾ ɪndə tʃɹʌbəl. jə ʌðɝ tu, kʌm wɪð mi."

Nynaeve summoned one of the bowlegged Saldaean soldiers. "You, watch these five and make sure they don't get into trouble. You other two, come with me."

ʃi stɑɹɾəd əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, bʌt wən ʃi dɪdn hɪɹ fʊtstɛps liv ðə bɔɹdwɔk, ʃi tɝnd wɪð ə fɹaʊn. ðə θɹi ɡɑɹdz stʊd təɡɛðɝ, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə sɪŋɡəl læntɝn, laɪkli kɝsɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz fəɹ nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ ənʌðɝ.

She started across the street, but when she didn't hear footsteps leave the boardwalk, she turned with a frown. The three guards stood together, looking at the single lantern, likely cursing themselves for not thinking to bring another.

"oʊ, fəɹ ðə laɪts seɪk," nɪneɪiv snæpt, ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hæn ən ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs. ʃi woʊv ə ɡloʊb ə laɪɾ əbʌv əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, kæstɪŋ ə kul, ivən ɪluməneɪʃən əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn hɝ. "liv ðə læntɝn."

"Oh, for the Light's sake," Nynaeve snapped, raising her hand and embracing the Source. She wove a globe of light above her fingers, casting a cool, even illumination across the ground around her. "Leave the lantern."

ðə tu sɑldəiənz kəmplaɪd, hɝiɪŋ æftɝ hɝ. ʃi stɛpt ʌp tə ðə tʃænlɝz dɔɹ, ðən woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ən pleɪst ɪɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf, ðə dɔɹ ən ðə tu soʊlʒɝz.

The two Saldaeans complied, hurrying after her. She stepped up to the chandler's door, then wove a ward against eavesdropping and placed it in the air around herself, the door and the two soldiers.

ʃi lʊkt ət wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz. "wʌts jəɹ neɪm?"

She looked at one of the soldiers. "What's your name?"

"tʃɹaɪbən, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd. hi wɑz ə hɔk-feɪs mæn wɪð ə ʃɔɹt, tʃɹɪmd mʌstæʃ ən ə skɑɹ əkɹɔs ɪz fɔɹhɛd. "ðæts lɝts," hi sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ ət ði ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝ, ə mæsɪv wɔl ʌv ə mæn u nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə si wɑz junəfɔɹmd əz ə kævəlɹimən.

"Triben, my Lady," he said. He was a hawk-faced man with a short, trimmed mustache and a scar across his forehead. "That's Lurts," he said, pointing at the other soldier, a massive wall of a man who Nynaeve had been surprised to see was uniformed as a cavalryman.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, tʃɹaɪbən," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "kɪk ðə dɔɹ oʊpən."

"All right, Triben," Nynaeve said. "Kick the door open."

tʃɹaɪbən dɪdn kwɛstʃən hɝ; hi dʒʌst ɹeɪzd ə buɾɪd fʊɾ ən kɪkt. ðə fɹeɪm kɹækt izəli ən ðə dɔɹ slæmd oʊpən, bʌɾ ɪf əɹ wɔɹd hæd bɪn pleɪs kɝɛkli, noʊbɑdi ɪn ðə bɪldɪŋ wəd bi eɪbəl tə hɪɹ. ʃi pikt ɪn. ðə ɹum smɛld ʌv wæks ən pɝfjumz, ən ðə wʊɾən flɔɹ wɑz mɑɹk baɪ numɝəs spɑts. dʒɹɪp mɑɹks; wæks ðət hæd bɪn klin ʌp ɔfən lɛft ə mɑɹk.

Triben didn't question her; he just raised a booted foot and kicked. The frame cracked easily and the door slammed open, but if her ward had been placed correctly, nobody in the building would be able to hear. She peeked in. The room smelled of wax and perfumes, and the wooden floor was marked by numerous spots. Drip marks; wax that had been cleaned up often left a mark.

"kwɪkli," ʃi sɛd tə ðə soʊlʒɝz, ɹilisɪŋ ðə wɔɹd bʌt meɪnteɪnɪŋ ðə ɡloʊb ə laɪt. "lɝts, ɡoʊ tə ðə bæk ə ðə ʃɑp ən wɑtʃ ði æli; meɪk sɝɾən noʊbɑdi ɪskeɪps. tʃɹaɪbən, wɪð mi."

"Quickly," she said to the soldiers, releasing the ward but maintaining the globe of light. "Lurts, go to the back of the shop and watch the alley; make certain nobody escapes. Triben, with me."

lɝts muvd wɪð sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ spid fəɹ ɪz bʌlk, teɪkɪŋ ɪz pəzɪʃən ɪn ðə bæk ɹum ə ðə ʃɑp.

Lurts moved with surprising speed for his bulk, taking his position in the back room of the shop.

hɝ ɡloʊb ɪluməneɪɾəd bæɹəlz fəɹ dɪpɪŋ kændəlz ən ə paɪl ə bɝnd nʌbz ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, bɑt fəɹ pɛniz tə bi ɹeɪ-mɛltəd. ə stɛɹkeɪs maʊntəd tə ðə ɹaɪt. ə smɔl ælkoʊv ɪn ðə fɹʌn ə ðə ʃɑp wɑz ðə stɔɹfɹɑnt, ən ɪt kənteɪn vɛɹiəs saɪzəz ən ʃeɪps ə kændəlz, fɹəm ðə stændɝd waɪt ɹɑd tə ðə pɝfjumd ən dɛkɝeɪɾəd bɹɪk. ɪf lɔɹəl wɑz ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ðɪs biɪŋ ðə pleɪs. . . .

Her globe illuminated barrels for dipping candles and a pile of burned nubs in the corner, bought for pennies to be re-melted. A staircase mounted to the right. A small alcove in the front of the shop was the storefront, and it contained various sizes and shapes of candles, from the standard white rod to the perfumed and decorated brick. If Loral was wrong about this being the place. . . .

bʌɾ ɛni ɡʊd sikɹəɾ ɑpɝeɪʃən wəɾ əv ə wɝkɪŋ fɹʌnt. nɪneɪiv hɝiɾ ʌp ðə stɛɹz, wʊd kɹikɪŋ bɪniθ əɹ weɪt. ðə bɪldɪŋ wɑz nɛɹoʊ. ɑn ði ʌpɝ flɔɹ, ʃi ən tʃɹaɪbən faʊn tu ɹumz. wʌn dɔɹ wɑz oʊpən ə kɹæk, soʊ nɪneɪiv dɪmd əɹ ɡloʊb ə laɪɾ ən woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛns lɪsənɝz ɪndə ðə ɹum. ðən ʃi bɝst ɪn, hɔk-feɪs tʃɹaɪbən fɑloʊɪŋ, hɪz sɔɹd skɹeɪpɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪts skæbɝɾ əz i pʊld ɪt fɹi.

But any good secret operation would have a working front. Nynaeve hurried up the stairs, wood creaking beneath her weight. The building was narrow. On the upper floor, she and Triben found two rooms. One door was open a crack, so Nynaeve dimmed her globe of light and wove a ward against listeners into the room. Then she burst in, hawk-faced Triben following, his sword scraping against its scabbard as he pulled it free.

ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn pɝsən ɪn ðə ɹum, ən oʊvɝweɪt mæn slipɪŋ ɑn ə mætʃɹəs ɑn ðə flɔɹ, blæŋkəts ɪn ə hip ɝaʊn ɪz fit. nɪneɪiv woʊv ə fju θɹɛdz ʌv ɛɹ, taɪɪŋ ɪm ʌp ɪn wʌn smuð moʊʃən. hɪz aɪz bʌlʒd oʊpən, ən i oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə skɹim, bʌt nɪneɪiv stʌft ɛɹ bɪtwin ɪz lɪps, ɡæɡɪŋ hɪm.

There was only one person in the room, an overweight man sleeping on a mattress on the floor, blankets in a heap around his feet. Nynaeve wove a few threads of Air, tying him up in one smooth motion. His eyes bulged open, and he opened his mouth to scream, but Nynaeve stuffed Air between his lips, gagging him.

ʃi tɝn tə tʃɹaɪbən ən nɑɾəd, taɪɪŋ ɔf əɹ wivz. ðeɪ lɛf ðə baʊn mæn ðɛɹ, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪz bɑnz, ən kɹɔs tə ði ʌðɝ dɔɹ. ʃi woʊv ənʌðɝ wiv əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum bɪfɔɹ ɛntɝɪŋ, ən ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ʃi dɪd - fəɹ ðə tu jʌŋɡɝ mɛn ɪn ðɪs ɹum ɹaʊz mʌtʃ mɔɹ kwɪkli. wʌn sæt boʊlt əpɹaɪt, lɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə jɛlp dʒʌst əz tʃɹaɪbən hɛɾəd əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz. tʃɹaɪbən pʌntʃt ɪm ɪn ðə stʌmək, nɑkɪŋ ði ɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz lʌŋz.

She turned to Triben and nodded, tying off her weaves. They left the bound man there, struggling against his bonds, and crossed to the other door. She wove another weave against eavesdropping into the room before entering, and it was a good thing she did - for the two younger men in this room roused much more quickly. One sat bolt upright, letting out a yelp just as Triben headed across the floorboards. Triben punched him in the stomach, knocking the air out of his lungs.

nɪneɪiv baʊn ɪm wɪð ə θɹɛɾ ʌv ɛɹ, ðən dɪd ðə seɪm fəɹ ði ʌðɝ jʌŋ mæn, hu wɑz ɹaʊzɪŋ dʒɹaʊsəli ɪn ɪz bʌŋk. ʃi toʊd ðə tu təwɔɹd hɝ, bɹaɪɾənɪŋ əɹ ɡloʊb ə laɪt, hæŋɪŋ ðə mɛn ʌp ɪn ði ɛɹ ə fju ɪntʃəz. ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ dəmɑni, wɪð dɑɹk hɛɹ ən kɹud feɪsəz, θɪn mʌstæʃɪz əbʌv ðɛɹ lɪps. boʊθ wɔɹ oʊnli ðɛɹ smɔlkloʊðz. ðeɪ sim tu oʊl tə bi əpɹɛntəsɪz.

Nynaeve bound him with a thread of Air, then did the same for the other young man, who was rousing drowsily in his bunk. She towed the two toward her, brightening her globe of light, hanging the men up in the air a few inches. They were both Domani, with dark hair and crude faces, thin mustaches above their lips. Both wore only their smallclothes. They seemed too old to be apprentices.

"aɪ θɪŋk wɪv ðə ɹaɪt pleɪs, nɪneɪiv sədaɪ," tʃɹaɪbən sɛd, wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə pɛɹ tə stæn bɪsaɪd hɝ.

"I think we have the right place, Nynaeve Sedai," Triben said, walking around the pair to stand beside her.

ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm.

She raised an eyebrow at him.

"ðoʊz ɑɹ noʊ tʃænlɝz əpɹɛntəsɪz," tʃɹaɪbən kəntɪnjud. hi slɪɾ ɪz sɔɹd bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ.

"Those are no chandler's apprentices," Triben continued. He slid his sword back into its sheath.

"kælʌsɪz ɑn ðə pɑmz, bʌt noʊ bɝnz ɑn ðɛɹ hænz? mʌsəld ɑɹmz? ən ðəɹ fɑɹ tu oʊld. ðət fɛloʊ ɑn ðə lɛft əz hæɾ ɪz noʊz bɹoʊkən ət list wʌns."

"Calluses on the palms, but no burns on their hands? Muscled arms? And they're far too old. That fellow on the left has had his nose broken at least once."

ʃi lʊkt kloʊsɝ; tʃɹaɪbən wɑz ɹaɪt. aɪ ʃʊɾə sin ðæt. stɪl, ʃi hæd noʊɾəst ði eɪdʒ.

She looked closer; Triben was right. I should have seen that. Still, she had noticed the age.

"wɪtʃ wʌn dʒju θɪŋk aɪ ʃəɾ ʌnɡæɡ," ʃi æskt kæʒəwəli, "ænd wɪtʃ wʌn ʃəɾ aɪ kɪl?"

"Which one do you think I should ungag," she asked casually, "and which one should I kill?"

boʊθ mɛn bɪɡæn tə skwɝm, aɪz waɪd. ðeɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn ðəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd nɛvɝ də ɛniθɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹt. ɪn fækt, ʃi pɹɑbli ʃʊdn əv ɪmplaɪɾ ɪt, bʌt pɹaɪvət dʒeɪlɝz laɪk ðiz ɹaɪld əɹ æŋɡɝ.

Both men began to squirm, eyes wide. They should have known that an Aes Sedai would never do anything of the sort. In fact, she probably shouldn't have implied it, but private jailers like these riled her anger.

"ðə wʌn ɑn ðə lɛf simz moʊst iɡɝ tə tɔk, leɪɾi," tʃɹaɪbən sɛd. "pɝhæps hɪl tɛl jə wʌt jə wɪʃ tə noʊ."

"The one on the left seems most eager to talk, Lady," Triben said. "Perhaps he will tell you what you wish to know."

ʃi nɑɾəd, ɹilisɪŋ ðə mænz ɡæɡ. hi bɪɡæn tə spik ɪmiɾiətli. "aɪ wɪl də wʌtɛvɝ jə seɪ! pliz, doʊn fɪl maɪ stʌmək wɪð ɪnsɛks! aɪ hævən dʌn ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ, aɪ pɹɑməs ju, aɪ - "

She nodded, releasing the man's gag. He began to speak immediately. "I will do whatever you say! Please, don't fill my stomach with insects! I haven't done anything wrong, I promise you, I - "

ʃi stʌf ði ɛɹ ɡæɡ bæk ɪn.

She stuffed the Air gag back in.

"tu mʌtʃ kəmpleɪnɪŋ," ʃi sɛd. "pɝhæps ði ʌðɝ wɪl noʊ tə hʌʃ ən spik wən spoʊkən tə." ʃi ɹilist ɪz ɡæɡ.

"Too much complaining," she said. "Perhaps the other will know to hush and speak when spoken to." She released his gag.

ðɪs mæn ɹɪmeɪn dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɑbviəsli tɛɹəfaɪd, bʌt seɪɪŋ nʌθɪŋ. ðə wʌn paʊɝ kəɾ ənɝv ðə moʊs hɑɹɾənd ə kɪlɝz.

This man remained dangling in the air, obviously terrified, but saying nothing. The One Power could unnerve the most hardened of killers.

"haʊ də aɪ ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə dʌnʒən?" ʃi æsk ðɪs mæn.

"How do I get into the dungeon?" she asked this man.

hi lʊk sɪk, bʌɾ i hæd pɹɑbli ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɛs ðət ʃid wɑn ðə dʌnʒən. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd bɝst ɪndə ðə ʃɑp æftɝ mɪdnaɪt kəz ʃid bɪn soʊld ə bæd kændəl.

He looked sick, but he had probably already guessed that she'd want the dungeon. It was unlikely that an Aes Sedai would burst into the shop after midnight because she'd been sold a bad candle.

"tʃɹæpdɔɹ," ðə mæn sɛd, "ʌndɝ ðə ɹʌɡ ɪn ðə ʃɑp fɹʌnt."

"Trapdoor," the man said, "under the rug in the shop front."

"ɛksələnt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. ʃi taɪɾ ɔf ðə wivz baɪndɪŋ ðə mɛnz hænz, ðən ɹipleɪs ðə ɡæɡ ɑn ðə wʌn u hæd spoʊkən. ʃi dɪdn liv əm hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ - ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə hæv tə pʊl əm əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn əɹ - ən ɪnstɛd lɛɾ əm wɔk ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn fit.

"Excellent," Nynaeve said. She tied off the weaves binding the men's hands, then replaced the gag on the one who had spoken. She didn't leave them hanging in the air - she didn't want to have to pull them along behind her - and instead let them walk on their own feet.

ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪbən fɛtʃ ði oʊvɝweɪt mæn fɹəm ði ʌðɝ ɹum, ðən hɝɾɪd ɔl θɹi daʊn ðə stɛɹz. bɪloʊ, ðeɪ mɛt ðə mʌskjəlɝ lɝts kipɪŋ kɛɹfəl wɑtʃ ɑn ði æli aʊt bæk. ə juθ sæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ən nɪneɪivz ɡloʊb ə laɪɾ ɪluməneɪɾəd ɪz feɪs, ə fɹaɪɾənd dəmɑni wʌn wɪð ʌnkɛɹɪktɝɪstɪkli laɪt hɛɹ ən hænz spɑɾəd wɪð bɝnz.

She had Triben fetch the overweight man from the other room, then herded all three down the stairs. Below, they met the muscular Lurts keeping careful watch on the alley out back. A youth sat on the floor in front of him, and Nynaeve's globe of light illuminated his face, a frightened Domani one with uncharacteristically light hair and hands spotted with burns.

"naʊ, ðæts ə tʃænlɝz əpɹɛntəs," tʃɹaɪbən sɛd, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz fɔɹhɛd skɑɹ. "ðeɪ pɹɑbli hæv ɪm duɪŋ ɔl ə ðə wɝk fəɹ ðə fɹʌnt."

"Now, that's a chandler's apprentice," Triben said, scratching his forehead scar. "They probably have him doing all of the work for the front."

"hi wɑz əslip ʌndɝ ðoʊz blæŋkəts oʊvɝ ðɛɹ." lɝts nɑɾəd tə ə ʃæɾoʊd paɪl ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ əz i dʒɔɪnd nɪneɪiv. "tʃɹaɪd tə skɹæmbəl aʊt ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ æftɝ jə wɛn ʌp ðə stɛɹz."

"He was asleep under those blankets over there." Lurts nodded to a shadowed pile in the corner as he joined Nynaeve. "Tried to scramble out the front door after you went up the stairs."

"bɹɪŋ hɪm," nɪneɪiv sɛd. ɪn ðə smɔl stɔɹfɹɑnt, tʃɹaɪbən pʊl bæk ðə ɹʌɡ, ðən juz ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz sɔɹd tə pɹɑd θɹu ðə slæts əntɪl i nɑkt əɡɛnst sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝniθ - hɪnʒɪz, nɪneɪiv əsumd. æftɝ ə lɪɾəl kɛɹfəl pɹaɪɪŋ, hi ɡɑt ðə tʃɹæpdɔɹ oʊpən. ə læɾɝ ɹitʃt daʊn ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs bɪloʊ.

"Bring him," Nynaeve said. In the small storefront, Triben pulled back the rug, then used the edge of his sword to prod through the slats until he knocked against something underneath - hinges, Nynaeve assumed. After a little careful prying, he got the trapdoor open. A ladder reached down into the darkness below.

nɪneɪiv stɛp fɔɹwɝd, bʌt tʃɹaɪbən hɛld ʌp ə hænd. "lɔɹd bæʃɪɹ wəd hæŋ mi ʌp baɪ maɪ oʊn stɝəps ɪf aɪ lɛt jə ɡoʊ fɝst, leɪɾi," hi sɛd. "noʊ tɛlɪŋ wʌt maɪt bi daʊn ðɛɹ." hi lɛpt ɪndə ðə hoʊl, slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə læɾɝ wɪð wʌn hænd, hɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. hi θʌmp tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪloʊ, ən nɪneɪiv ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz. mɛn! ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd fəɹ lɝts tə wɑtʃ ðə dʒeɪlɝz, ðən ɹilis ðɛɹ bɑnz soʊ ðeɪ kəd klaɪm daʊn. ʃi ɡeɪv itʃ ə ðɛm ə stɝn lʊk; ðən ʃi pɹəsiɾəd daʊn ðə læɾɝ wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪbənz ɹɪdɪkjələs flɛɹ, livɪŋ lɝts tə hɝd ðə dʒeɪlɝz æftɝ.

Nynaeve stepped forward, but Triben held up a hand. "Lord Bashere would hang me up by my own stirrups if I let you go first, Lady," he said. "No telling what might be down there."
