He leaped into the hole, sliding down the ladder with one hand, his sword in the other. He thumped to the ground below, and Nynaeve rolled her eyes. Men! She gestured for Lurts to watch the jailers, then released their bonds so they could climb down. She gave each of them a stern look; then she proceeded down the ladder without Triben's ridiculous flair, leaving Lurts to herd the jailers after.

ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ ɡloʊb ə laɪɾ ən sɝveɪd ðə sɛlɝ. ðə wɔlz wɝ stoʊn, wɪtʃ meɪɾ əɹ fil mʌtʃ lɛs nɝvəs əbaʊt ðə weɪɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ əbʌv. ðə flɔɹ wɑz pæk dɝt, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə wʊɾən dɔɹweɪ bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔl əkɹɔs fɹəm hɝ. tʃɹaɪbən wɑz lɪsnɪŋ əɾ ɪt.

She raised her globe of light and surveyed the cellar. The walls were stone, which made her feel much less nervous about the weight of the building above. The floor was packed dirt, and there was a wooden doorway built into the wall across from her. Triben was listening at it.

ʃi nɑɾəd, ən i pʊld ɪɾ oʊpən, dɑɹɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ iɡɝli. ðə sɑldəiənz sim tə bi pɪkɪŋ ʌp səm hæbəts fɹəm ði il. nɪneɪiv fɑloʊd, pɹipɛɹɪŋ wivz ʌv ɛɹ, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. bɪhaɪn hɝ, ðə sʌlən dʒeɪlɝz bɪɡæn tə klaɪm daʊn ðə læɾɝ, fɑloʊd baɪ lɝts.

She nodded, and he pulled it open, darting inside eagerly. The Saldaeans seemed to be picking up some habits from the Aiel. Nynaeve followed, preparing weaves of Air, just in case. Behind her, the sullen jailers began to climb down the ladder, followed by Lurts.

ðəɹ wɑzn mʌtʃ tə si ɪn ði ʌðɝ ɹum. tu dʌnʒən sɛlz wɪð θɪk wʊɾən dɔɹz, ə teɪbəl wɪð səm stulz bɪsaɪɾ ɪt, ən ə lɑɹdʒ wʊɾən tʃɹʌŋk. nɪneɪiv sɛn əɹ ɡloʊb ə laɪt tə ðə kɔɹnɝ əz hɔk-feɪs tʃɹaɪbən ɪnspɛktɪd ðə tʃɹʌŋk. hi lɪftəd ðə lɪd, ðən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, pʊlɪŋ aʊt sɛvɹəl ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ naɪvz. eɪdz fəɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ. nɪneɪiv ʃɪvɝd. ʃi tɝn hɑɹʃ aɪz ɑn ðə dʒeɪlɝz bɪhaɪn hɝ.

There wasn't much to see in the other room. Two dungeon cells with thick wooden doors, a table with some stools beside it, and a large wooden trunk. Nynaeve sent her globe of light to the corner as hawk-faced Triben inspected the trunk. He lifted the lid, then raised an eyebrow, pulling out several glittering knives. Aids for questioning. Nynaeve shivered. She turned harsh eyes on the jailers behind her.

ʃi əntaɪd ðə ɡæɡ ɑn ðə wʌn u hæd spoʊkən. "kiz?" ʃi æskt.

She untied the gag on the one who had spoken. "Keys?" she asked.

"bɑɾəm ə ðə tʃɹʌŋk," sɛd ðə θʌɡ. ði oʊvɝweɪt dʒeɪlɝ - ðə liɾɝ ə ðə ɡɹup, noʊ daʊt, əz i dɪdnt ʃɛɹ ə ɹum - ʃɑɾ ɪm ə fjʊɹiəs ɡlæns. nɪneɪiv dʒɝk ðə liɾɝ ɪndə ði ɛɹ. "doʊn pɹəvoʊk mi," ʃi ɡɹaʊld. "ɪts ɔlɹɛɾi fɑɹ tu leɪɾ ət naɪt fəɹ ɹizənəbəl pipəl tə bi əweɪk."

"Bottom of the trunk," said the thug. The overweight jailer - the leader of the group, no doubt, as he didn't share a room - shot him a furious glance. Nynaeve jerked the leader into the air. "Don't provoke me," she growled. "It's already far too late at night for reasonable people to be awake."

ʃi nɑɾəd tə tʃɹaɪbən, ən i dʌɡ aʊt ðə kiz ən oʊpən ðə sɛl dɔɹz. ðə fɝst sɛl wɑz ɛmpti; ðə sɛkənd wʌn hɛld ə dɪʃɛvəld wʊmən, stɪl wɛɹɪŋ ə faɪn dəmɑni dʒɹɛs, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz sɔɪld. leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝ wɑz dɝɾi ən ɹæɡəɾ ən ʃi kɝld əɡɛns ðə wɔl, dʒɹaʊzi, bɛɹli ivən noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðət ðə dɔɹ wɑz oʊpən. nɪneɪiv kɑɾ ə wɪf ʌv ə stɛntʃ ðæt, ʌp əntɪl ðət moʊmənt, hæd bɪn kʌvɝd baɪ ðə sɛn ə ɹɑɾɪŋ fɪʃ. hjumən ɛkskɹəmən ən ən ənwɑʃt bɑɾi. laɪkli, ðət wɑz wʌn ɹizən fəɹ loʊkeɪɾɪŋ ðə dʌnʒən hɪɹ ɪn ðə ɡʌlz fist.

She nodded to Triben, and he dug out the keys and opened the cell doors. The first cell was empty; the second one held a disheveled woman, still wearing a fine Domani dress, though it was soiled. Lady Chadmar was dirty and ragged and she curled against the wall, drowsy, barely even noticing that the door was open. Nynaeve caught a whiff of a stench that, up until that moment, had been covered by the scent of rotting fish. Human excrement and an unwashed body. Likely, that was one reason for locating the dungeon here in the Gull's Feast.

nɪneɪiv ɪnheɪld ʃɑɹpli ət siɪŋ haʊ ðə wʊmən wɑz biɪŋ tʃɹiɾəd. haʊ kəd ɹænd əlaʊ ðɪs? ðə wʊmən hɝsɛlf hæd dʌn ðɪs vɛɹi θɪŋ tə ʌðɝz, bʌt ðət dɪdn meɪk ɪt ɹaɪt fəɹ ɪm tə stup tə hɝ lɛvəl.

Nynaeve inhaled sharply at seeing how the woman was being treated. How could Rand allow this? The woman herself had done this very thing to others, but that didn't make it right for him to stoop to her level.

ʃi weɪv fəɹ tʃɹaɪbən tə kloʊz ðə dɔɹ; ðən ʃi sæt daʊn ɑn wʌn ə ðə ɹumz stulz, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə θɹi dʒeɪlɝz. bɪhaɪnd, lɝts ɡɑɹɾəd ðə weɪ aʊt, kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ðə pʊɹ əpɹɛntəs. ði oʊvɝweɪt dʒeɪlɝ stɪl hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ.

She waved for Triben to close the door; then she sat down on one of the room's stools, regarding the three jailers. Behind, Lurts guarded the way out, keeping an eye on the poor apprentice. The overweight jailer still hung in the air.

ʃi niɾəd ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ʃi cʊɾə æskt ɹænd fəɹ pɝmɪʃən tə vɪzət ðə dʒeɪl ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪn duɪŋ soʊ, ʃi wʊɾə ɹɪskt əlɝɾɪŋ ðiz mɛn ðət ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə bi vɪzəɾəd.

She needed information. She could have asked Rand for permission to visit the jail in the morning, but in doing so, she would have risked alerting these men that they were going to be visited.

ʃi wɑz dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn sɝpɹaɪz ən ɪntɪmɪdeɪʃən tə ɹɪvil wʌt hæd bɪn hɪɾən.

She was depending on surprise and intimidation to reveal what had been hidden.

"naʊ," ʃi sɛd tə ðə θɹi, "aɪ æm gɑnə æsk səm kwɛstʃənz. jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ænsɝ. aɪm nɑt sɝɾən wʌɾ aɪm gɑnə də wɪð jə jɛt, soʊ ɹilaɪz ɪts bɛs tə bi vɛɹi ɑnəst wɪð mi."

"Now," she said to the three, "I am going to ask some questions. You are going to answer. I'm not certain what I'm going to do with you yet, so realize it's best to be very honest with me."

ðə tu ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn lʊkt ʌp ət ði ʌðɝ mæn, floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ði ɪnvɪzəbəl wivz ʌv ɛɹ. ðeɪ nɑɾəd.

The two on the ground looked up at the other man, floating in the invisible weaves of Air. They nodded.

"ðə mæn u wɑz bɹɔt tə ju," ʃi sɛd. "ðə mɛsənʒɝ ə ðə kɪŋ. wən dɪɾ i fɝst ɝaɪv?"

"The man who was brought to you," she said. "The messenger of the King. When did he first arrive?"

"tu mʌnθs əɡoʊ," wʌn ə ðə tʌfs sɛd - ðə wʌn wɪð ðə lɑɹdʒ tʃɪn ən ðə bɹoʊkən noʊz.

"Two months ago," one of the toughs said - the one with the large chin and the broken nose.

"ɝaɪvd ɪn ə sæk wɪð ðə kændəl nʌbz fɹəm leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝz mænʃən, dʒʌs laɪk ɔl ðə pɹɪznɝz."

"Arrived in a sack with the candle nubs from Lady Chadmar's mansion, just like all the prisoners."

"jɔɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz?"

"Your instructions?"

"hoʊl hɪm," ði ʌðɝ tʌf sɛd. "kip ɪm əlaɪv. wi dɪdnt noʊ mʌtʃ, ɝ, leɪɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"Hold him," the other tough said. "Keep him alive. We didn't know much, er, Lady Aes Sedai.

dʒɔɹdʒɪn ɪz ðə wʌn u dʌz ɔl ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ."

Jorgin is the one who does all the questioning."

ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət ðə fæt mæn. "jɔɹ dʒɔɹdʒɪn?"

She looked up at the fat man. "You're Jorgin?"

hi nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli.

He nodded reluctantly.

"ænd wʌt wɝ jəɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz?"

"And what were your instructions?"

dʒɔɹdʒɪn dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd.

Jorgin didn't respond.

nɪneɪiv saɪd. "lʊk," ʃi sɛd tə hɪm. "aɪ æm ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən æm baʊn baɪ maɪ wɝd. ɪf jə tɛl mi wʌɾ aɪ wɑnə noʊ, əl si ðət jə ɑɹ nɑt səspɛktəɾ ɪn ðə dɛθ. ðə dʒɹæɡən dʌzn kɛɹ əbaʊt jə θɹi, ʌðɝwaɪz jə wʊdn stɪl bi hɪɹ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðɪs lɪɾəl . . . stɑpoʊvɝ ə jʊɹz."

Nynaeve sighed. "Look," she said to him. "I am Aes Sedai, and am bound by my word. If you tell me what I want to know, I will see that you are not suspected in the death. The Dragon doesn't care about you three, otherwise you wouldn't still be here in charge of this little . . . stopover of yours."

"ɪf wi tɔk, wi ɡoʊ fɹi?" ðə fæt mæn sɛd, aɪɪŋ hɝ. "jɔɹ wɝd?"

"If we talk, we go free?" the fat man said, eyeing her. "Your word?"

nɪneɪiv ɡlænst əbaʊt ðə taɪni ɹum wɪð ə dɪsæɾəsfaɪd aɪ. ðeɪ hæd lɛf leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ən ðə dɔɹ wɑz pækt wɪð klɔθ tə mʌfəl skɹimz. ðə sɛl wəd bi dɑɹk, stʌfi ən kɹæmpt. mɛn u wəd wɝk ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs bɛɹli dɪzɝv laɪf, lɛɾ əloʊn fɹiɾəm.

Nynaeve glanced about the tiny room with a dissatisfied eye. They had left Lady Chadmar in the dark, and the door was packed with cloth to muffle screams. The cell would be dark, stuffy and cramped. Men who would work a place like this barely deserved life, let alone freedom.

bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ sɪknəs tə dil wɪð. "jɛs," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ðə wɝd bɪɾɝ ɪn əɹ maʊθ. "æn jə noʊ ðæts bɛɾɝ ðən jə dɪzɝv."

But there was a much larger sickness to deal with. "Yes," Nynaeve said, the word bitter in her mouth. "And you know that's better than you deserve."

dʒɔɹdʒɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd. "lɛt mi daʊn, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən əl ænsɝ jəɹ kwɛstʃənz."

Jorgin hesitated, then nodded. "Let me down, Aes Sedai, and I'll answer your questions."

ʃi dɪd soʊ. ðə mæn maɪt nɑt noʊ ɪt, bʌt ʃi hæd vɛɹi lɪɾəl əθɔɹəɾi tə stæn ɑn; ʃi wʊdn ɹɪzɔɹt tə hɪz mɛθədz ʌv ɪkstʃɹæktɪŋ ænsɝz, ən ʃi wɑz æktɪŋ wɪθaʊt ɹændz nɑlədʒ. ðə dʒɹæɡən pɹɑbli wʊdn ɹiækt wɛl wən i dɪskʌvɝd ðət ʃid bɪn pɹaɪɪŋ - nɑɾ ənlɛs ʃi kəd pɹizɛn ɪm wɪð dɪskʌvɝiz.

She did so. The man might not know it, but she had very little authority to stand on; she wouldn't resort to his methods of extracting answers, and she was acting without Rand's knowledge. The Dragon probably wouldn't react well when he discovered that she'd been prying - not unless she could present him with discoveries.

dʒɔɹdʒɪn sɛd tə ðə bɹoʊkən-noʊz θʌɡ, "mɔɹd, fɛtʃ mi ə stul."

Jorgin said to the broken-nosed thug, "Mord, fetch me a stool."

mɔɹd ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv fəɹ əpɹuvəl, wɪtʃ ʃi ɡeɪv wɪð ə kɝt nɑd. əz dʒɔɹdʒɪn sɛɾəld ɪz bʌlk ɑntu ðə stul, hi lin fɔɹwɝd, hænz klæsp bɪfɔɹ hɪm. hi ɹɪzɛmbəld ə hʌlkɪŋ biɾəl tɪpt ʌp ɑn ɪts saɪd.

Mord glanced at Nynaeve for approval, which she gave with a curt nod. As Jorgin settled his bulk onto the stool, he leaned forward, hands clasped before him. He resembled a hulking beetle tipped up on its side.

"aɪ doʊn si wʌt jə nid fɹəm mi," ðə mæn sɛd. "ju sim tə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi. jə noʊ əbaʊt maɪ fəsɪlɪɾi ən əbaʊt ðə pipəl ɪts hɛld. wʌt mɔɹ ɪz ðəɹ tə noʊ?"

"I don't see what you need from me," the man said. "You seem to know everything already. You know about my facility and about the people it has held. What more is there to know?"

fəsɪlɪɾi? səm wɝd fəɹ ɪt. "ðæɾ ɪz maɪ oʊn bɪznəs," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ə stɛɹ wɪtʃ ʃi hoʊpt ɪmplaɪd ðət ðə kənsɝnz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ nɑt tə bi kwɛstʃənd. "tɛl mi, haʊ dɪd ðə mɛsənʒɝ daɪ?"

Facility? Some word for it. "That is my own business," Nynaeve said, giving him a stare which she hoped implied that the concerns of the Aes Sedai were not to be questioned. "Tell me, how did the messenger die?"

"wɪθaʊt dɪɡnəɾi," dʒɔɹdʒɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "laɪk ɔl mɛn, ɪn maɪ ɪkspɪɹiəns."

"Without dignity," Jorgin replied. "Like all men, in my experience."

"ɡɪv mi spɪsɪfɪks, əɹ jəl ɡoʊ bæk tə hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ."

"Give me specifics, or you'll go back to hanging in the air."

"aɪ oʊpən ðə sɛl dɔɹ ə fju deɪz bæk tə fid hɪm. hi wɑz dɛd."

"I opened the cell door a few days back to feed him. He was dead."

"haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ ɪt bɪn sɪns jud fɛd hɪm, ðɛn?"

"How long had it been since you'd fed him, then?"

dʒɔɹdʒɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "aɪ doʊn stɑɹv maɪ ɡɛsts, leɪɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ dʒʌst . . . ɛnkɝɪdʒ əm tə bi fɹi wɪð wʌt ðeɪ noʊ."

Jorgin snorted. "I don't starve my guests, Lady Aes Sedai. I just . . . encourage them to be free with what they know."

"æn haʊ mʌtʃ ɛnkɝɪdʒmən dɪd jə ɡɪv ðə mɛsənʒɝ?"

"And how much encouragement did you give the messenger?"

"nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə kɪl hɪm," ðə dʒeɪlɝ sɛd dɪfɛnsɪvli.

"Not enough to kill him," the jailer said defensively.

"oʊ, kʌm naʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðə mæn ɹɪmeɪn fəɹ mʌnθs ɪn jəɹ pəzɛʃən, pɹəzuməbli hɛlθi ɔl ðət taɪm. ðɛn, ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ hiz tə bi bɹɔt bɪfɔɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, hi sʌɾənli daɪz? jə ɔlɹɛɾi hæv maɪ pɹɑməs ʌv æmnəsti. tɛl mi hu bɹaɪb jə tə kɪl ɪm ən əl si ðət jəɹ pɹətɛktəd."

"Oh, come now," Nynaeve said. "The man remained for months in your possession, presumably healthy all that time. Then, the day before he is to be brought before the Dragon Reborn, he suddenly dies? You already have my promise of amnesty. Tell me who bribed you to kill him and I'll see that you're protected."

ðə dʒeɪlɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪt wɑzn laɪk ðæt. aɪm tɛlɪŋ ju, hi dʒʌs daɪd. ɪt hæpənz səmtaɪmz."

The jailer shook his head. "It wasn't like that. I'm telling you, he just died. It happens sometimes."

"aɪ taɪɝ ə jəɹ ɡeɪmz."

"I tire of your games."

"ɪts nɑɾ ə ɡeɪm, bɝn ju!" dʒɔɹdʒɪn snɑɹəld. "ju θɪŋk ə mæn kəd ɡɛt fɑɹ ɪn maɪ pɹəfɛʃən ɪf ɪt wɝ noʊn ðət hiɾ æksɛpt ə bɹaɪb tə kɪl wʌn ə hɪz ɡɛsts? jə kʊdn tʃɹʌst ɪm ɛni fɝðɝ ðən jə kəɾ ə laɪɪŋ il!"

"It's not a game, burn you!" Jorgin snarled. "You think a man could get far in my profession if it were known that he'd accept a bribe to kill one of his guests? You couldn't trust him any further than you could a lying Aiel!"

ʃi lɛt ðət læs kɑmɛn slaɪd, ðoʊ ə mæn laɪk ðɪs wʌn kəd nɛvɝ bi "tʃɹʌstɪd."

She let that last comment slide, though a man like this one could never be "trusted."

"lʊk," dʒɔɹdʒɪn sɛd, "ðæt wɑzn ðə taɪp ə pɹɪznɝ jə kɪl, ɛniweɪ. ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑns tə noʊ wɛɹ ðə kɪŋ ɪz. hud kɪl ði oʊnli wʌn wɪð ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əbaʊɾ ɪt? ðət mæn wɑz wɝθ ɡʊd mʌni."

"Look," Jorgin said, "that wasn't the type of prisoner you kill, anyway. Everybody wants to know where the King is. Who'd kill the only one with information about it? That man was worth good money."

"soʊ hiz nɑt dɛd," nɪneɪiv sɝmaɪzd. "hu dɪd jə sɛl ɪm tə?"

"So he's not dead," Nynaeve surmised. "Who did you sell him to?"

"oʊ, hiz dɛd," ðə dʒeɪlɝ sɛd wɪð ə tʃʌkəl. "ɪf aɪ hæd soʊl hɪm, aɪ wʊdn əv lɪv lɔŋ æftɝwɝd. jə lɝn ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ kwɪkli, duɪŋ wʌɾ aɪ du."

"Oh, he's dead," the jailer said with a chuckle. "If I had sold him, I wouldn't have lived long afterward. You learn that sort of thing quickly, doing what I do."

ʃi tɝn tə ði ʌðɝ tu θʌɡz. "ɪz i laɪɪŋ?" ʃi æskt ə ðɛm. "ə hʌnʒɹəd ɡoʊl mɑɹks tə ðə wʌn ə jə hu kən ɡɪmi pɹuf ðəɾ i ɪz."

She turned to the other two thugs. "Is he lying?" she asked of them. "A hundred gold marks to the one of you who can give me proof that he is."

mɔɹd ɡlænst əɾ ɪz bɑs, ðən ɡɹɪməst. "fɔɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd ɪn ɡoʊld, aɪd sɛl jə maɪ oʊn mʌðɝ, leɪɾi. bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ wʊd. dʒɔɹdʒɪnz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ, ðoʊ. ðət bɑɾi wɑz ɡʊɾ ən dɛd. ðə dʒɹæɡənz mɛn tʃɛkt wən ðeɪ bɹɔt ðə leɪɾi tə ʌs."

Mord glanced at his boss, then grimaced. "For a hundred in gold, I'd sell you my own mother, Lady. Burn me, but I would. Jorgin's telling the truth, though. That body was good and dead. The Dragon's men checked when they brought the lady to us."

soʊ ɹænd hæd kənsɪɾɝd ðət pɑsəbɪləɾi. bʌt ʃi stɪl hæd noʊ pɹuf ðət ðiz mɛn wɝ tɛlɪŋ əɹ ðə tʃɹuθ. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tə haɪd, ðeɪd wɝk hɑɹd tə bɛɹi ɪt dip. ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹaɪ ə dɪfɹən pæθ.

So Rand had considered that possibility. But she still had no proof that these men were telling her the truth. If there was something to hide, they'd work hard to bury it deep. She decided to try a different path.

"wʌt dɪd jə dɪskʌvɝ, ðɛn," ʃi sɛd, "əbaʊt ðə kɪŋz loʊkeɪʃən?"

"What did you discover, then," she said, "about the King's location?"

dʒɔɹdʒɪn dʒʌst saɪd. "laɪk aɪ toʊl ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡənz mɛn, ən laɪk aɪ toʊld leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi lændəd hɪɹ ɪn ðə dʌnʒənz hɝsɛlf. ðət mæn nu sʌmθɪŋ, bʌɾ i wʊdn spik ɪt."

Jorgin just sighed. "Like I told the Lord Dragon's men, and like I told Lady Chadmar before she landed here in the dungeons herself. That man knew something, but he wouldn't speak it."

"kʌm naʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ʃuɾɪŋ ə ɡlæns ət ðə tʃɛst wɪð ɪts ʃɑɹp ɪkwɪpmənt. ʃi hæd tə lʊk əweɪ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ɪɾ æŋɡɝd hɝ. "ə mæn ə jəɹ . . . skɪl? ən jə kʊdn pɹaɪ wʌn sɪmpəl fækt aʊɾ ə hɪm?"

"Come now," Nynaeve said, shooting a glance at the chest with its sharp equipment. She had to look away again before it angered her. "A man of your . . . skill? And you couldn't pry one simple fact out of him?"

"dɑɹk wʌn teɪk mi ɪf aɪm laɪɪŋ!" ðə dʒeɪlɝz feɪs flʌʃt əz ɪf ðɪs wɝ ə mæɾɝ ə pɹaɪd fəɹ hɪm. "aɪv nɛvɝ sin ə mæn ɹɪzɪs laɪk ðət wʌn dɪd! ə pɹɪɾi fɛðɝ ʌv ə mæn laɪk ɪm ʃʊɾə bɹoʊkən wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ ɛnkɝɪdʒmən əɾ ɔl. bʌɾ i dɪdnt. hi wəd spik ɑn ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ðə θɪŋz wi wɑntəd!" dʒɔɹdʒɪn lin fɔɹwɝd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ hi dɪɾ ɪt, leɪɾi. bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt!

"Dark One take me if I'm lying!" The jailer's face flushed as if this were a matter of pride for him. "I've never seen a man resist like that one did! A pretty feather of a man like him should have broken without much encouragement at all. But he didn't. He would speak on anything other than the things we wanted!" Jorgin leaned forward. "I don't know how he did it, Lady. Burn me, but I don't!

ɪts laɪk səm . . . fɔɹs hæɾ əhoʊld ə hɪz tʌŋ. ɪt wɑz laɪk i kʊdn tɔk. ivən ɪf hid wɑntəd tə!"

It's like some . . . force had ahold of his tongue. It was like he couldn't talk. Even if he'd wanted to!"

ðə tu θʌɡz mʌɾɝd tə ðɛmsɛlvz, lʊkɪŋ æpɹɪhɛnsɪv. ɪt sim ðət nɪneɪivz kwɛstʃənɪŋ hæd hɪɾ ə nɝv.

The two thugs muttered to themselves, looking apprehensive. It seemed that Nynaeve's questioning had hit a nerve.

"soʊ jə pʊʃt ɪm tu hɑɹd," nɪneɪiv ɡɛst. "æn ðæts haʊ hi daɪd."

"So you pushed him too hard," Nynaeve guessed. "And that's how he died."

"teɪk ɪɾ ɔl, wʊmən!" ðə dʒeɪlɝ ɡɹaʊld. "blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! aɪ dɪdn kɪl hɪm! səmtaɪmz, pipəl dʒʌs daɪ."

"Take it all, woman!" the jailer growled. "Blood and bloody ashes! I didn't kill him! Sometimes, people just die."

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə bɪliv hɪm. dʒɔɹdʒɪn wɑz ə ɹɛtʃ ʌv ə mæn u kəd juz ə dɛkeɪd duɪŋ tʃɔɹz bɪniθ ði aɪz ʌv ə wɪzdəm. bʌɾ i wɑzn laɪɪŋ.

Unfortunately, she was coming to believe him. Jorgin was a wretch of a man who could use a decade doing chores beneath the eyes of a Wisdom. But he wasn't lying.

soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ əɹ ɡɹæn plænz. ʃi saɪd, stændɪŋ ʌp, ɹilaɪzɪŋ dʒʌs haʊ taɪɝd ʃi ɹɪli wɑz.

So much for her grand plans. She sighed, standing up, realizing just how tired she really was.

laɪt! ðɪs skim wɑz mɔɹ laɪkli tə meɪk ɹænd ɪksploʊɾ əɾ əɹ ðən pɝsweɪɾ ɪm tə lɪsən tə hɝ kaʊnsəl. ʃi niɾəd tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə mænʃən fəɹ səm slip. pɝhæps təmɑɹoʊ ʃid bi eɪbəl tə θɪŋk ʌp ə bɛɾɝ weɪ tə ʃoʊ ɹænd ðət ʃi wɑz ɑn ɪz saɪd.

Light! This scheme was more likely to make Rand explode at her than persuade him to listen to her counsel. She needed to return to the mansion for some sleep. Perhaps tomorrow she'd be able to think up a better way to show Rand that she was on his side.

ʃi weɪv fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz tə teɪk ðə dʒeɪlɝ ən ɪz mɛn bæk ʌp əbʌv. æftɝ ðæt, ʃi woʊv ɛɹ tə ʃʌt ðə sɛl dɔɹ ɑn maɪləsɹ tʃædmɑɝ. nɪneɪiv wəd si ðət ðə wʊmənz kəndɪʃənz wɝ ɪmpɹuvd. dɪspɪkəbəl hjumən biɪŋ əɹ nɑt, ʃi ʃəd nɑt bi tʃɹiɾəd ðɪs weɪ. ɹænd wəɾ əv tə ʌndɝstæn ðət wən ʃi ɪkspleɪn ɪt tə hɪm. waɪ, maɪləsɹ lʊk soʊ peɪl ʃi maɪt bi kʌmɪŋ daʊn wɪð ðə ʃeɪks! æbsənli, nɪneɪiv wɔk tə ðə vjuɪŋ slɪɾ ət ðə tɑp ə ðə sɛl dɔɹ, ðən woʊv ə dɛlvɪŋ ə spɪɹət tə meɪk sɝɾən ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑɾ ɪl.

She waved for the guards to take the jailer and his men back up above. After that, she wove Air to shut the cell door on Milisair Chadmar. Nynaeve would see that the woman's conditions were improved. Despicable human being or not, she should not be treated this way. Rand would have to understand that when she explained it to him. Why, Milisair looked so pale she might be coming down with the shakes! Absently, Nynaeve walked to the viewing slit at the top of the cell door, then wove a Delving of Spirit to make certain the woman was not ill.

əz sun əz ʃi bɪɡæn ðə dɛlvɪŋ, nɪneɪiv fɹoʊz. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn maɪləsɹz bɑɾi tæks baɪ ɪɡzɔstʃən. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn dɪziz, pɝhæps hʌŋɡɝ.

As soon as she began the Delving, Nynaeve froze. She had expected to find Milisair's body taxed by exhaustion. She had expected to find disease, perhaps hunger.

ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn pɔɪzən.

She had not expected to find poison.

kɝsɪŋ, sʌɾənli əlɝt, nɪneɪiv θɹu oʊpən ðə sɛl dɔɹ ən ɹʌʃt ɪnsaɪd. jɛs, ʃi kəd si ɪɾ izəli θɹu ðə dɛlvɪŋ. tɑɹtʃɹət lif. nɪneɪiv hɝsɛlf hæd ɡɪvən ðət tə ə haʊn u hæd niɾəd tə bi pʊt daʊn. ɪt wɑz ə kɑmən ɪnʌf plænt, ən hæɾ ə vɛɹi bɪɾɝ fleɪvɝ. nɑt ðə bɛs pɔɪzən, əz ɪt hæd sətʃ ən ənplɛzən teɪst, ən jɛt hæd tə bi ɪndʒɛstəd.

Cursing, suddenly alert, Nynaeve threw open the cell door and rushed inside. Yes, she could see it easily through the Delving. Tarchrot leaf. Nynaeve herself had given that to a hound who had needed to be put down. It was a common enough plant, and had a very bitter flavor. Not the best poison, as it had such an unpleasant taste, and yet had to be ingested.

jɛs, ɪt wɑz ə bæd pɔɪzən - ənlɛs ðə pɝsən jə wɝ pɔɪzənɪŋ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi kæptɪv ən hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə it ðə fud jə ɡeɪv hɝ. nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn ə hilɪŋ, wivɪŋ ɔl faɪv paʊɝz, stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ ðə pɔɪzən ən stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ maɪləsɹz bɑɾi. ɪt wɑz ə ɹɛləɾɪvli izi hilɪŋ, əz tɑɹtʃɹət lif wɑzn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli stʃɹɔŋ. jə iðɝ hæd tə juz ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪt - əz ʃi hæd wɪð ðə haʊnd - əɹ jə hæd tə ədmɪnəstɝ ɪt sɛvɹəl taɪmz fəɹ ɪt tə teɪk ɪfɛkt. bʌɾ ɪf jə dɪɾ ɪt sloʊli laɪk ðæt, ðə pɝsən jə kɪld wɪð ɪt wəd sim tə daɪ nætʃɹəli.

Yes, it was a bad poison - unless the person you were poisoning was already captive and had no choice but to eat the food you gave her. Nynaeve began a Healing, weaving all five Powers, strangling the poison and strengthening Milisair's body. It was a relatively easy Healing, as tarchrot leaf wasn't particularly strong. You either had to use a lot of it - as she had with the hound - or you had to administer it several times for it to take effect. But if you did it slowly like that, the person you killed with it would seem to die naturally.

wʌns maɪləsɹ wɑz seɪf, nɪneɪiv bɝs fɹəm ðə sɛl. "stɑp!" ʃi bɛloʊɾ ət ðə mɛn. "dʒɔɹdʒɪn!"

Once Milisair was safe, Nynaeve burst from the cell. "Stop!" she bellowed at the men. "Jorgin!"

lɝts, ət ðə bæk, tɝnd wɪð sɝpɹaɪz. hi ɡɹæb ðə dʒeɪlɝ dʒɔɹdʒɪn baɪ ði ɑɹm ən spʌn ɪm ɝaʊnd.

Lurts, at the back, turned with surprise. He grabbed the jailer Jorgin by the arm and spun him around.

"hu pɹipɛɹz ðə pɹɪznɝz fud?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd, stɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm.

"Who prepares the prisoner's food?" Nynaeve demanded, stalking toward him.

"ðə fud?" dʒɔɹdʒɪn æskt, lʊkɪŋ kənfjuzd. "ðæts wʌn ə kɝbz dʒɑbz. waɪ?"

"The food?" Jorgin asked, looking confused. "That's one of Kerb's jobs. Why?"

"kɝb?"

"Kerb?"

"ðə læd," dʒɔɹdʒɪn sɛd. "noʊbɑdi ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ən əpɹɛntəs wi faʊn əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz ə fju mʌnθs bæk. kwaɪɾ ə lʌki faɪnd - əɹ læst əpɹɛntəs ɹæn ɔf ɑn ʌs, ən ðɪs wʌn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi tʃɹeɪn ɪn  - "

"The lad," Jorgin said. "Nobody important. An apprentice we found among the refugees a few months back. Quite a lucky find - our last apprentice ran off on us, and this one was already trained in  - "

nɪneɪiv hʌʃt ɪm wɪð ə ɹeɪz hænd, sʌɾənli æŋkʃəs. "ðə bɔɪ! wɛɹ ɪz hi?"

Nynaeve hushed him with a raised hand, suddenly anxious. "The boy! Where is he?"

"hi wɑz dʒʌs hɪɹ . . ." lɝts sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ʌp. "wɛnt wɪð - "

"He was just here . . ." Lurts said, glancing up. "Went with - "

ðəɹ wɑz ə sʌɾən skɹæmbəlɪŋ fɹəm əbʌv. nɪneɪiv kɝst, kɔlɪŋ fəɹ tʃɹaɪbən tə kætʃ ðə bɔɪ.

There was a sudden scrambling from above. Nynaeve cursed, calling for Triben to catch the boy.

ʃi ʃʌvd əɹ weɪ tə ðə læɾɝ ən bɪɡæn klaɪmɪŋ. ʃi dɑɹɾɪd aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ʃɑp əbʌv, hɝ ɡloʊɪŋ laɪt fɑloʊɪŋ. ðə tu θʌɡz stʊd kaʊɝɪŋ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ɹum, lʊkɪŋ kənfjuzd, ən ə sɑldəiən ɡɑɹd stʊd wɪð ə sɔɹd pʊld ɑn ðɛm. hi lʊkt əɾ əɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋli.

She shoved her way to the ladder and began climbing. She darted out into the shop above, her glowing light following. The two thugs stood cowering in the center room, looking confused, and a Saldaean guard stood with a sword pulled on them. He looked at her questioningly.

"ðə bɔɪ!" ʃi sɛd.

"The boy!" she said.

tʃɹaɪbən ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə ʃɑp dɔɹ. ɪt wɑz oʊpən. pɹipɛɹɪŋ wivz ʌv ɛɹ, nɪneɪiv dæʃt aʊɾ ɑntu ðə stʃɹit.

Triben glanced toward the shop door. It was open. Preparing weaves of Air, Nynaeve dashed out onto the street.

ðɛɹ, ʃi faʊn ðə bɔɪ, kɝb, ɪn ðə mʌɾi stʃɹit, hɛl daʊn baɪ ðə fɔɹ daɪs-pleɪɪŋ wɝkɝz ʃid bɹɔt fɹəm ðə mænʃən. ivən əz ʃi stɛpt ɔf ðə bɔɹdwɔk ɑntu ðə stʃɹit, ðeɪ pʊl ðə stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ, fɹæntɪk bɔɪ tə hɪz fit. ðə læst sɑldəiən stʊɾ ət ðə dɔɹweɪ, sɔɹɾ aʊt, əz ɪf hid bɪn ɹʌʃɪŋ ɪn tə si ɪf ʃi wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ.

There, she found the boy, Kerb, in the muddy street, held down by the four dice-playing workers she'd brought from the mansion. Even as she stepped off the boardwalk onto the street, they pulled the struggling, frantic boy to his feet. The last Saldaean stood at the doorway, sword out, as if he'd been rushing in to see if she was in danger.

"hi boʊltəɾ aʊɾ ə ðə dɔɹ, ɛɛs sədaɪ," wʌn ə ðə wɝkɝz sɛd, "æz ɪf ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf wɑz tʃeɪsɪŋ hɪm. jəɹ soʊlʒɝ ɹæn oʊvɝ tə si ɪf jə wɝ ɪn deɪnʒɝ, bʌt wi fɪɡjɝɾ ɪɾəd bi bɛs tə snætʃ ðɪs læd bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɡɛɾ əweɪ. dʒʌst ɪn keɪs."

"He bolted out of the door, Aes Sedai," one of the workers said, "as if the Dark One himself was chasing him. Your soldier ran over to see if you were in danger, but we figured it'd be best to snatch this lad before he could get away. Just in case."

nɪneɪiv lɛɾ aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ tə kɑm hɝsɛlf. "ju dɪd wɛl," ʃi sɛd. ðə juθ stʃɹʌɡəld, wikli.

Nynaeve let out a breath to calm herself. "You did well," she said. The youth struggled, weakly.

"ju dɪd wɛl ɪndid."

"You did well indeed."

tʃæptɝ θɝɾiθɹi

CHAPTER 33

eɪ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən "ðɪs," ɹænd dɪklɛɹd, "hæd bɛɾɝ bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt."

A Conversation with the Dragon "This," Rand declared, "had better be important."

nɪneɪiv tɝn tə faɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn stændɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ tə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. hi wɔɹ ə dɑɹk ɹɛd ɹoʊb wɪð blæk dʒɹæɡənz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ʌp ði ɑɹmz. hɪz stʌmp wɑz hɪɾən ɪn ðə foʊlz ə ðə lɛf sliv. ðoʊ hɪz hɛɹ wɑz tɔsəl fɹəm slip, hɪz aɪz wɝ əlɝt.

Nynaeve turned to find the Dragon Reborn standing in the doorway to the sitting room. He wore a dark red robe with black dragons embroidered up the arms. His stump was hidden in the folds of the left sleeve. Though his hair was tousled from sleep, his eyes were alert.

hi stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ɛvɝ ðə kɪŋ - ivən naʊ, lɔŋ æftɝ mɪdnaɪɾ ən dʒʌst əweɪkənd, hi wɔkt əz ɪf i wɝ æbsəlutli sɝɾən ə hɪmsɛlf. səm sɝvəns hæd bɹɔɾ ə pɑɾ ə hɑt ti, ən i fɪld ə kʌp əz mɪn fɑloʊɾ ɪm ɪndə ðə ɹum. ʃi ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ə slipɪŋ ɹoʊb; ðə ɹoʊbz wɝ wʌn ə ðə fæʃənz ə ðə dəmɑni, ən hɝz wɑz ə jɛloʊ sɪlk, ðə wiv fɑɹ θɪnɝ ðən ɹænz. il meɪɾənz tʊk ʌp pəzɪʃənz baɪ ðə dɔɹ, laʊnʒɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪnʒli deɪnʒɝəs weɪ.

He strode into the sitting room, ever the king - even now, long after midnight and just awakened, he walked as if he were absolutely certain of himself. Some servants had brought a pot of hot tea, and he filled a cup as Min followed him into the room. She also wore a sleeping robe; the robes were one of the fashions of the Domani, and hers was of yellow silk, the weave far thinner than Rand's. Aiel maidens took up positions by the door, lounging in their strangely dangerous way.

ɹænd tʊk ə ɡʌlp fɹəm ɪz kʌp. ɪt wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ ən hɑɹɾɝ tə si ɪn ɪm ðə bɔɪ nɪneɪiv hæd noʊn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. hæɾ ɪz dʒɔ ɔlweɪz bɪn sɛt wɪð ðoʊz laɪnz ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən? wən hæɾ ɪz stɛp ɡɹoʊn soʊ ʃʊɹ, hɪz pɑstʃɝ soʊ dɪmændɪŋ? ðɪs mæn ɔlmoʊst simd ən . . . ɪntɝpɹɪteɪʃən ə ðə ɹænd ʃid wʌns noʊn. laɪk ə stætʃu, kɑɹv fɹəm ɹɑk tə lʊk laɪk hɪm, bʌɾ ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd ɪn hɪɹoʊɪk laɪnz.

Rand took a gulp from his cup. It was getting harder and harder to see in him the boy Nynaeve had known in the Two Rivers. Had his jaw always been set with those lines of determination? When had his step grown so sure, his posture so demanding? This man almost seemed an . . . interpretation of the Rand she'd once known. Like a statue, carved from rock to look like him, but exaggerated in heroic lines.

"wɛl?" ɹænd dɪmændəd. "hu ɪz ðɪs?"

"Well?" Rand demanded. "Who is this?"

ðə jʌŋ əpɹɛntəs, kɝb, sæt taɪɾ ɪn ɛɹ əpɑn wʌn ə ðə ɹumz kʊʃən bɛntʃɪz. nɪneɪiv ɡlænst ət hɪm, ðən ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ən woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ. ɹænd lʊkt əɾ əɹ ʃɑɹpli. "ju tʃænəld?" hi æskt. hi kəd sɛns wən ʃi dɪd soʊ wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ pɹikɔʃənz;

The young apprentice, Kerb, sat tied in Air upon one of the room's cushioned benches. Nynaeve glanced at him, then Embraced the Source and wove a ward against eavesdropping. Rand looked at her sharply. "You channeled?" he asked. He could sense when she did so without taking precautions;

hi fɛlt ɡus bʌmps ɑn ðə flɛʃ, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪnz ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃənz.

he felt goose bumps on the flesh, according to Egwene and Elayne's investigations.

"ə wɔɹd," ʃi sɛd, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə bi kaʊd. "læst aɪ tʃɛkt, aɪ dɪdnt nid jəɹ pɝmɪʃən tə tʃænəl. juv ɡɹoʊn haɪ ən maɪɾi, ɹænd ælθɹ, bʌt doʊn fɝɡɛt ðəɾ aɪ pæɾəld jəɹ bæksaɪd wən jə wɝ bɛɹli əz tɔl əz ə mænz ʃɪnz."

"A ward," she said, refusing to be cowed. "Last I checked, I didn't need your permission to channel. You've grown high and mighty, Rand al'Thor, but don't forget that I paddled your backside when you were barely as tall as a man's shins."

wʌns ðət wʊɾə ɡɑɾən ə ɹiækʃən fɹəm hɪm, ɪf oʊnli ə hʌf ʌv ənɔɪəns. naʊ hi dʒʌs lʊkt ət hɝ. ðoʊz aɪz ə hɪz simd, ət taɪmz, ðə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm ðət hæd tʃeɪnʒd ðə moʊst.

Once that would have gotten a reaction from him, if only a huff of annoyance. Now he just looked at her. Those eyes of his seemed, at times, the part of him that had changed the most.

hi saɪd. "waɪ hæv jə wækən mi, nɪneɪiv? hu ɪz ðɪs spɪnli, tɛɹəfaɪd juθ? ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn ɛniwʌn ɛls u sɛn ðət mɛsədʒ ðɪs taɪm ə naɪt, aɪɾ əv sɛn əm tə bæʃɪɹ fəɹ ə flɑɡɪŋ."

He sighed. "Why have you wakened me, Nynaeve? Who is this spindly, terrified youth? If it had been anyone else who sent that message this time of night, I'd have sent them to Bashere for a flogging."

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd ət kɝb. "aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs 'spɪnli, tɛɹəfaɪd juθ' noʊz wɛɹ ðə kɪŋ ɪz."

Nynaeve nodded at Kerb. "I think this 'spindly, terrified youth' knows where the King is."

ðət ɡɑt ɹændz ətɛnʃən, ən mɪnz əz wɛl. ʃid pɔɹd hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti ən wɑz linɪŋ əɡɛnst ə wɔl. waɪ wɝn ðeɪ mɛɹid?

That got Rand's attention, and Min's as well. She'd poured herself a cup of tea and was leaning against a wall. Why weren't they married?

"ðə kɪŋ?" ɹænd æskt. "ɡɹeɪndəl tu, ðɛn. haʊ dʒju noʊ ðɪs, nɪneɪiv? wɛɹ dɪd jə faɪn hɪm?"

"The King?" Rand asked. "Graendal too, then. How do you know this, Nynaeve? Where did you find him?"

"æt ðə dʌnʒən wɛɹ jə sɛn maɪləsɹ tʃædmɑɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, aɪɪŋ hɪm. "ɪɾ ɪz tɛɹəbəl, ɹænd ælθɹ. juv noʊ ɹaɪt tə tʃɹiɾ ə pɝsən ɪn sətʃ ə mænɝ."

"At the dungeon where you sent Milisair Chadmar," Nynaeve said, eyeing him. "It is terrible, Rand al'Thor. You have no right to treat a person in such a manner."

hi dɪdn ɹaɪz tə ðət kɑmɛn iðɝ. ɪnstɛd, hi sɪmpli wɔkt oʊvɝ tə kɝb. "hi hɝd sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ði ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃən?"

He didn't rise to that comment either. Instead, he simply walked over to Kerb. "He heard something from the interrogation?"

"noʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk i kɪl ðə mɛsənʒɝ. aɪ noʊ fəɹ ə fæk ðəɾ i tʃɹaɪd tə pɔɪzən maɪləsɹ. ʃiɾ əv bɪn dɛd baɪ ði ɛn ə ðə wik ɪf aɪ hædn hil hɝ."

"No," Nynaeve said. "But I think he killed the messenger. I know for a fact that he tried to poison Milisair. She'd have been dead by the end of the week if I hadn't Healed her."

ɹænd ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv, ən ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ɪm kənɛktɪŋ ðə kɑmɛns tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn duɪŋ. "ju ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi faɪnəli sɛd, "ʃɛɹ mʌtʃ wɪð ɹæts, aɪ hæv kʌm tə ɹilaɪz. jə ɑɹ ɔlweɪz ɪn pleɪsəz wɛɹ jə ɑɹ nɑt wɑntəd."

Rand glanced at Nynaeve, and she could almost feel him connecting the comments to figure out what she had been doing. "You Aes Sedai," he finally said, "share much with rats, I have come to realize. You are always in places where you are not wanted."

nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd. "ɪf aɪd steɪɾ əweɪ, ðən maɪləsɹ wəd bi daɪɪŋ ən kɝb wəd bi fɹi."

Nynaeve snorted. "If I'd stayed away, then Milisair would be dying and Kerb would be free."

"aɪ əsum juv æskt ɪm u ɔɹɾɝd ɪm tə kɪl ðə mɛsənʒɝ."

"I assume you've asked him who ordered him to kill the messenger."

"nɑt jɛt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ dɪd faɪn ðə pɔɪzən əmʌŋ ɪz θɪŋz, haʊɛvɝ, ən kənfɝm ðəɾ i hæd pɹipɛɹd fud boʊθ fəɹ maɪləsɹ ən fəɹ ðə mɛsənʒɝ." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ kəntɪnjuɪŋ. "ɹænd, aɪm nɑt sɝɾən ðət hɪl bi eɪbəl tə ænsɝ əɹ kwɛstʃənz. aɪ dɛlv hɪm, ən waɪl hiz nɑt sɪk fɪzɪkəli, ðɛɹz . . . sʌmθɪŋ ðɛɹ. ɪn ɪz maɪnd."

"Not yet," Nynaeve said. "I did find the poison among his things, however, and confirmed that he had prepared food both for Milisair and for the messenger." She hesitated before continuing. "Rand, I'm not certain that he'll be able to answer our questions. I Delved him, and while he's not sick physically, there's . . . something there. In his mind."

"wʌt dʒju min?" ɹænd æsk sɔfli.

"What do you mean?" Rand asked softly.

"ə blɑk ə səm sɔɹt," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðə dʒeɪlɝ sim fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd - ivən sɝpɹaɪzd - ðət ðə mɛsənʒɝ hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə ɹɪzɪst ɪz 'kwɛstʃənɪŋ.' aɪ θɪŋk ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn səm blɑk ɑn ðət mæn tu, sʌmθɪŋ tə kip ɪm fɹəm ɹɪvilɪŋ tu mʌtʃ."

"A block of some sort," Nynaeve said. "The jailer seemed frustrated - even surprised - that the messenger had been able to resist his 'questioning.' I think there must have been some block on that man too, something to keep him from revealing too much."

"kəmpʌlʃən," ɹænd sɛd. hi spoʊk ɑfhændɪdli, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz ti tə hɪz lɪps.

"Compulsion," Rand said. He spoke offhandedly, raising his tea to his lips.

kəmpʌlʃən wɑz dɑɹk, ivəl. ʃid fɛlt ɪt hɝsɛlf; ʃi stɪl ʃɪvɝd wən ʃi kənsɪɾɝd wʌt mɑɡiɾin hæd dʌn tə hɝ. ən ðət hæd bɪn oʊnli ə smɔl θɪŋ, ɹimuvɪŋ səm mɛmɹiz.

Compulsion was dark, evil. She'd felt it herself; she still shivered when she considered what Moghedien had done to her. And that had been only a small thing, removing some memories.

"fju ɑɹ əz skɪld wɪð kəmpʌlʃən əz ɡɹeɪndəl," ɹænd sɛd mjuzɪŋli. "pɝhæps ðɪs ɪz ðə kɑnfɝmeɪʃən aɪv bɪn lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ. jɛs . . . ðɪs kəd bi ə ɡɹeɪt dɪskʌvɝi ɪndid, nɪneɪiv. ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk mi fɝɡɛt haʊ jə əbteɪn ɪt."

"Few are as skilled with Compulsion as Graendal," Rand said musingly. "Perhaps this is the confirmation I've been looking for. Yes . . . this could be a great discovery indeed, Nynaeve. Great enough to make me forget how you obtained it."

ɹænd ɹaʊndəd ðə bɛntʃ ən lin daʊn tə mit ðə jʌŋ mænz aɪz.

Rand rounded the bench and leaned down to meet the young man's eyes.

"ɹilis hɪm," ɹænd kəmændəd hɝ.

"Release him," Rand commanded her.

ʃi kəmplaɪd.

She complied.

"tɛl mi," ɹænd sɛd tə kɝb, "hu toʊl jə tə pɔɪzən ðoʊz pipəl?"

"Tell me," Rand said to Kerb, "who told you to poison those people?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ!" ðə bɔɪ skwikt. "aɪ dʒʌst - "

"I don't know anything!" the boy squeaked. "I just - "

"stɑp," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "du jə bɪliv ðəɾ aɪ kən kɪl ju?"

"Stop," Rand said softly. "Do you believe that I can kill you?"

ðə bɔɪ fɛl saɪlən ən - ðoʊ nɪneɪiv wʊdn əv θɔɾ ɪt pɑsəbəl - hɪz blu aɪz oʊpənd waɪɾɝ.

The boy fell silent and - though Nynaeve wouldn't have thought it possible - his blue eyes opened wider.

"du jə bɪliv ðəɾ ɪf aɪ sɪmpli sɛd ðə wɝd," ɹænd kəntɪnjuɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹi, kwaɪət vɔɪs, "jɔɹ hɑɹt wəd stɑp biɾɪŋ? aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. dʒju bɪliv ðəɾ aɪ kən teɪk jəɹ laɪf, əɹ jəɹ soʊl ɪtsɛlf, ɪf aɪ soʊ mʌtʃ əz wɪl ɪt tə hæpən?"

"Do you believe that if I simply said the word," Rand continued in his eerie, quiet voice, "your heart would stop beating? I am the Dragon Reborn. Do you believe that I can take your life, or your soul itself, if I so much as will it to happen?"

nɪneɪiv sɔ ɪɾ əɡɛn, ðə pətinə ʌv dɑɹknəs ɝaʊn ɹænd, ðəɾ ɔɹə ðət ʃi kʊdn kwaɪt bi sɝɾən wɑz ðɛɹ. ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ ti tə hɝ lɪps - ən faʊn ðəɾ ɪt hæd sʌɾənli ɡɹoʊn bɪɾɝ ən steɪl, əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn lɛf tə sɪt tu lɔŋ.

Nynaeve saw it again, the patina of darkness around Rand, that aura that she couldn't quite be certain was there. She raised her tea to her lips - and found that it had suddenly grown bitter and stale, as if it had been left to sit too long.

kɝb slaʊtʃt daʊn ən bɪɡæn tə kɹaɪ.

Kerb slouched down and began to cry.

"spik," ɹænd kəmændəd.

"Speak," Rand commanded.

ðə juθ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌɾ oʊnli ə ɡɹoʊn keɪm aʊt. hi wɑz soʊ tʃɹænsfɪks baɪ ɹænd ðəɾ i dɪdnt - əɹ kʊdnt - blɪŋk ðə swɛt fɹəm ɪz aɪz.

The youth opened his mouth, but only a groan came out. He was so transfixed by Rand that he didn't - or couldn't - blink the sweat from his eyes.

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd θɔtfəli. "ðɪs ɪz kəmpʌlʃən, nɪneɪiv. ʃiz hɪɹ! aɪ wɑz ɹaɪt." hi lʊkt ət nɪneɪiv. "ju wɪl əv tə ənɹævəl ðə wɛb ə kəmpʌlʃən, waɪp ɪt fɹəm ɪz maɪnd, bɪfɔɹ i kən tɛl əs wʌɾ i noʊz."

"Yes," Rand said thoughtfully. "This is Compulsion, Nynaeve. She's here! I was right." He looked at Nynaeve. "You will have to unravel the web of Compulsion, wipe it from his mind, before he can tell us what he knows."

"wʌt?" ʃi æskt ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli.

"What?" she asked incredulously.

"aɪ hæv lɪɾəl skɪl wɪð ðɪs kaɪndə wivɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd wɪð ə weɪv ə hɪz hænd. "aɪ səspɛk ðət jə kən ɹimuv kəmpʌlʃən, ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ. ɪts sɪməlɝ tə hilɪŋ, ɪn ə weɪ. juz ðə seɪm wiv ðət kɹieɪts kəmpʌlʃən, bʌt ɹɪvɝs ɪt."

"I have little skill with this kind of weaving," Rand said with a wave of his hand. "I suspect that you can remove Compulsion, if you try. It is similar to Healing, in a way. Use the same weave that creates Compulsion, but reverse it."

ʃi fɹaʊnd. hilɪŋ ðə pʊɹ bɔɪ saʊndəd laɪk ə faɪn aɪdiə - ɛvɹi waʊnd ʃəd bi hild, æftɝ ɔl. bʌt tʃɹaɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ʃid nɛvɝ dʌn bɪfɔɹ, ən duɪŋ soʊ ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹænd, wɑz nɑɾ əpilɪŋ. wʌɾ ɪf ʃi dɪɾ ɪt ɹɔŋ ən sʌmhaʊ hɝt ðə bɔɪ?

She frowned. Healing the poor boy sounded like a fine idea - every wound should be Healed, after all. But trying something she'd never done before, and doing so in front of Rand, was not appealing. What if she did it wrong and somehow hurt the boy?

ɹænd sæt daʊn ɑn ðə kʊʃən bɛntʃ siɾ əkɹɔs fɹəm ðə juθ, mɪn wɔkɪŋ oʊvɝ tə sɪt bɪsaɪd hɪm. ʃi wɑz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ əɹ ti wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs; əpɛɹənli, hɝz hæd spɔɪld əz sʌɾənli əz nɪneɪivz hæd.

Rand sat down on the cushioned bench seat across from the youth, Min walking over to sit beside him. She was regarding her tea with a grimace; apparently, hers had spoiled as suddenly as Nynaeve's had.

ɹænd wɑtʃt nɪneɪiv, weɪɾɪŋ.

Rand watched Nynaeve, waiting.

"ɹænd, aɪ - "

"Rand, I - "

"dʒʌs tʃɹaɪ ɪt," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ kæn tɛl jə haʊ ɪts dʌn spəsɪfɪkli, nɑt fəɹ ə wʊmən, bʌt jə ɑɹ klɛvɝ. ɪm sɝɾən jə kən mænədʒ."

"Just try it," Rand said. "I can't tell you how it is done specifically, not for a woman, but you are clever. I'm certain you can manage."

hɪz ʌnɪntɛnʃənəli peɪtʃɹənaɪzɪŋ toʊn sɛn əɹ bæk ɪndə ə ɹeɪdʒ. biɪŋ əz taɪɝɾ əz ʃi wɑz dɪdn hɛlp. ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd kɝb, ən woʊv ɔl faɪv paʊɝz. hɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd bæk ən fɔɹθ, ðoʊ hi kʊdn si ðə wivz.

His unintentionally patronizing tone sent her back into a rage. Being as tired as she was didn't help. She gritted her teeth, turning toward Kerb, and wove all five Powers. His eyes darted back and forth, though he couldn't see the weaves.

nɪneɪiv leɪɾ ə vɛɹi laɪt hilɪŋ əkɹɔs hɪm, kɑzɪŋ ɪm tə stɪfən. ʃi woʊv ə sɛpɹət laɪn ə spɪɹət, dɛlvɪŋ ɪndə hɪz hɛɾ əz dɛləkətli əz ʃi kʊd, pɹɑɾɪŋ ət ðə wivz ðət klʌmpt əkɹɔs ɪz maɪnd. jɛs, ʃi kəd si ɪt naʊ, ə kɑmplɛks wɛb meɪd fɹəm laɪnz ə spɪɹət, ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ. ɪt wɑz hɔɹəbəl, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt wɪð əɹ maɪnz aɪ, kɹɪskɹɔsɪŋ ðə juθs bɹeɪn. bɪts ə ðə wiv tʌtʃt hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, laɪk taɪni hʊks, dʒʌɾɪŋ dip ɪndə ðə bɹeɪn ɪtsɛlf.

Nynaeve laid a very light Healing across him, causing him to stiffen. She wove a separate line of Spirit, Delving into his head as delicately as she could, prodding at the weaves that clumped across his mind. Yes, she could see it now, a complex web made from lines of Spirit, Air and Water. It was horrible, looking at it with her mind's eye, crisscrossing the youth's brain. Bits of the weave touched here and there, like tiny hooks, jutting deep into the brain itself.

ɹɪvɝs ðə wiv, ɹænd hæd sɛd. ðət wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm izi. ʃiɾ əv tə pʊl ðə wɛb ə kəmpʌlʃən ɔf leɪɝ baɪ leɪɝ, ən ɪf ʃi meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk, ʃi kəd vɛɹi izəli kɪl hɪm. ʃi ɔlmoʊs bækt əweɪ.

Reverse the weave, Rand had said. That was far from easy. She'd have to pull the web of Compulsion off layer by layer, and if she made a mistake, she could very easily kill him. She almost backed away.

bʌɾ u ɛls wɑz ðɛɹ? kəmpʌlʃən wɑz ə fɔɹbɪɾən wiv, ən ʃi daʊɾɪd ðət kɔɹəl əɹ ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ɛni ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð ɪt. ɪf nɪneɪiv stɑp naʊ, ɹænd wəd dʒʌst sɛn fəɹ ði ʌðɝz ən æsk əm tə də ɪt. ðeɪɾ oʊbeɪ hɪm, læfɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ hænz ət nɪneɪiv, ði æksɛptɪɾ u θɔt hɝsɛlf ə fʊl ɛɛs sədaɪ.

But who else was there? Compulsion was a forbidden weave, and she doubted that Corele or the others had any experience with it. If Nynaeve stopped now, Rand would just send for the others and ask them to do it. They'd obey him, laughing behind their hands at Nynaeve, the Accepted who thought herself a full Aes Sedai.

wɛl, ʃi hæd dɪskʌvɝd nu weɪz ə hilɪŋ! ʃi hæd hɛlp klɛnz ðə teɪn fɹəm ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪtsɛlf! ʃi hæd hil stɪlɪŋ ən dʒɛntəlɪŋ!

Well, she had discovered new ways of Healing! She had helped cleanse the taint from the One Power itself! She had Healed stilling and gentling!

ʃi kəd də ðɪs.

She could do this.

ʃi wɝkt kwɪkli, wivɪŋ ə mɪɹɝ ɪmədʒ ə ðə fɝs leɪɝ ə kəmpʌlʃən. itʃ jus ə ðə paʊɝ wɑz ɪɡzækt, bʌt ɹɪvɝs fɹəm ðə pæɾɝn ɔlɹɛɾi woʊvən ɪn ðə bɔɪz maɪnd. nɪneɪiv leɪɾ əɹ wiv daʊn kɛɹfəli, hɛzɪɾəntli, ən əz ɹænd hæd sɛd, boʊθ pʌft əweɪ ən vænɪʃt.

She worked quickly, weaving a mirror image of the first layer of Compulsion. Each use of the Power was exact, but reversed from the pattern already woven in the boy's mind. Nynaeve laid her weave down carefully, hesitantly, and as Rand had said, both puffed away and vanished.

haʊ hæɾ i noʊn? ʃi ʃɪvɝd, θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv wʌt sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd sɛɾ əbaʊt hɪm. mɛmɹiz fɹəm ənʌðɝ laɪf, mɛmɹiz i hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹizən ðə kɹieɪɾɝ əlaʊɾ əm tə fɝɡɛt ðɛɹ pæs lɪvz. noʊ mæn ʃəɾ əv tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə feɪljɝz ə luz θɝɪn tɛləmən.

How had he known? She shivered, thinking of what Semirhage had said about him. Memories from another life, memories he had no right to. There was a reason the Creator allowed them to forget their past lives. No man should have to remember the failures of Lews Therin Telamon.

ʃi kəntɪnjud, leɪɝ æftɝ leɪɝ, stʃɹɪpɪŋ əweɪ ðə kəmpʌlʃənz wivz laɪk ə hɛdʒ-dɑktɝ ɹimuvɪŋ bændədʒəz fɹəm ə wundəd lɛɡ. ɪt wɑz ɪɡzɔstɪŋ wɝk, bʌt fʊlfɪlɪŋ. itʃ wiv fɪkst ə ɹɔŋ, hil ðə juθ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ, meɪd sʌmθɪŋ dʒʌst ə hɛɹ mɔɹ ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə wɝld.

She continued, layer after layer, stripping away the Compulsion's weaves like a hedge-doctor removing bandages from a wounded leg. It was exhausting work, but fulfilling. Each weave fixed a wrong, healed the youth a little more, made something just a hair more right in the world.

ɪt tʊk ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ən aʊɝ, ən wɑz ə ɡɹuɪlɪŋ ɪkspɪɹiəns. bʌt ʃi dɪɾ ɪt. əz ðə læs leɪɝ ə kəmpʌlʃən vænɪʃt, ʃi lɛɾ aʊɾ ən ɪɡzɔstəd saɪ ən ɹilis ðə wʌn paʊɝ, kənvɪns ðət ʃi kʊdn tʃænəl ə sɪŋɡəl θɹɛd mɔɹ ɪf ɪt wɝ tə seɪv əɹ laɪf. ʃi wɑbəld oʊvɝ tə ə tʃɛɹ ən slʌmp daʊn. mɪn, ʃi noʊɾəst, hæd kɝld ʌp ɑn ðə bɛntʃ sit bɪsaɪd ɹænd ən hæd fɔlən əslip.

It took the better part of an hour, and was a grueling experience. But she did it. As the last layer of Compulsion vanished, she let out an exhausted sigh and released the One Power, convinced that she couldn't channel a single thread more if it were to save her life. She wobbled over to a chair and slumped down. Min, she noticed, had curled up on the bench seat beside Rand and had fallen asleep.

bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt slip. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑtʃt, əz ɪf siɪŋ θɪŋz nɪneɪiv kəd nɑt. hi stʊɾ ʌp ən wɔk tə kɝb. ɪn əɹ dɪzid steɪt, nɪneɪiv hædnt noʊɾəst ðə jʌŋ tʃænlɝz feɪs.

But he did not sleep. The Dragon Reborn watched, as if seeing things Nynaeve could not. He stood up and walked to Kerb. In her dizzied state, Nynaeve hadn't noticed the young chandler's face.

ɪt wɑz ɑdli blæŋk, laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ə pɝsən deɪz fɹəm ə stʃɹɔŋ bloʊ tə ðə hɛd.

It was oddly blank, like that of a person dazed from a strong blow to the head.

ɹænd loʊɝd hɪmsɛlf tə wʌn ni, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ðə juθs tʃɪn ɪn ɪz hænd, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə hɪz aɪz.

Rand lowered himself to one knee, cradling the youth's chin in his hand, staring into his eyes.

"wɛɹ?" hi æsk sɔfli. "wɛɹ ɪz ʃi?"

"Where?" he asked softly. "Where is she?"

ðə juθ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ən ə laɪn ə dʒɹul likt aʊt ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɪt.

The youth opened his mouth, and a line of drool leaked out the side of it.

"wɛɹ ɪz ʃi? " ɹænd ɹɪpiɾɪd.

"Where is she? " Rand repeated.

kɝb moʊnd, aɪz stɪl blæŋk, tʌŋ pɑɹɾɪŋ ɪz lɪps dʒʌst slaɪtli.

Kerb moaned, eyes still blank, tongue parting his lips just slightly.

"ɹænd!" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "stɑp ɪt! wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ tə hɪm?"

"Rand!" Nynaeve said. "Stop it! What are you doing to him?"

"aɪ hæv dʌn nʌθɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli, nɑt lʊkɪŋ təwɔɹd hɝ. "ðɪs ɪz wʌt jə dɪd, nɪneɪiv, ɪn ənɹævəlɪŋ ðoʊz wivz. ɡɹeɪndəlz kəmpʊlʃənz ɑɹ paʊɝfəl - bʌt kɹud, ɪn səm weɪz. ʃi fɪlz ə maɪnd wɪð kəmpʌlʃən tə sətʃ ən ɪkstɛn əz tə ɪɹeɪs pɝsənælɪɾi ən ɪntəlɛkt, livɪŋ bɪhaɪn ə pʌpəɾ u wɝks oʊnli əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə hɝ dɝɛkt kəmænz."

"I have done nothing," Rand said quietly, not looking toward her. "This is what you did, Nynaeve, in unraveling those weaves. Graendal's Compulsions are powerful - but crude, in some ways. She fills a mind with Compulsion to such an extent as to erase personality and intellect, leaving behind a puppet who works only according to her direct commands."

"bʌɾ i wɑz eɪbəl tə ɪntɝæk dʒʌs moʊməns əɡoʊ!"

"But he was able to interact just moments ago!"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪf jə æsk ðə mɛn ət ðə dʒeɪl, ðəl tɛl jə ðɪs wʌn wɑz sloʊ ʌv θɔɾ ən ɹɛɹli spoʊk tə ðɛm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹil pɝsən ɪn ðɪs hɛd, oʊnli leɪɝd wivz ə kəmpʌlʃən.

Rand shook his head. "If you ask the men at the jail, they'll tell you this one was slow of thought and rarely spoke to them. There was no real person in this head, only layered weaves of Compulsion.

ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz klɛvɝli dɪzaɪn tə waɪp wʌtɛvɝ pɝsənælɪɾi ðɪs pʊɹ ɹɛtʃ hæɾ ən ɹipleɪs ɪt wɪð ə kɹitʃɝ u wəɾ ækt ɪɡzækli əz ɡɹeɪndəl wɪʃt. aɪv sin ɪt dʌzənz ə taɪmz."

Instructions cleverly designed to wipe whatever personality this poor wretch had and replace it with a creature who would act exactly as Graendal wished. I've seen it dozens of times."

dʌzənz ə taɪmz? nɪneɪiv θɔt wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ. juv sin ɪt, əɹ luz θɝɪn sɔ ɪt? wɪtʃ mɛmɹiz ɹul jə ɹaɪt naʊ?

Dozens of times? Nynaeve thought with a shiver. You've seen it, or Lews Therin saw it? Which memories rule you right now?

ʃi lʊkt ət kɝb, sɪk tə hɝ stʌmək. hɪz aɪz wɝn blæŋk fɹəm biɪŋ deɪzd əz ʃid θɔt; ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ ɛmpti ðən ðæt. wən nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn jʌŋɡɝ, nu tə hɝ ɹoʊl əz wɪzdəm, ə wʊmən hæd bɪn bɹɔt tə hɝ u hæd fɔlən ɔf ə hɝ wæɡən. ðə wʊmən hæd slɛp fəɹ deɪz, ən wən ʃid faɪnəli ɔfoʊkən, ʃid hæɾ ə stɛɹ laɪk ðɪs wʌn. noʊ hɪn ðət ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɛniwʌn, noʊ klu ðət ðəɹ wɑz ɛni soʊl lɛft ɪn ðə hʌsk ðət wɑz əɹ bɑɾi.

She looked at Kerb, sick to her stomach. His eyes weren't blank from being dazed as she'd thought; they were more empty than that. When Nynaeve had been younger, new to her role as Wisdom, a woman had been brought to her who had fallen off of her wagon. The woman had slept for days, and when she'd finally awoken, she'd had a stare like this one. No hint that she recognized anyone, no clue that there was any soul left in the husk that was her body.

ʃid daɪɾ əbaʊɾ ə wik leɪɾɝ.

She'd died about a week later.

ɹænd spoʊk tə kɝb əɡɛn. "aɪ niɾ ə loʊkeɪʃən," ɹænd sɛd. "sʌmθɪŋ. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛni vɛstɪdʒ wɪðɪn jə ðət ɹɪzɪstɪd, ɛni skɹæp ðət fɔt hɝ, aɪ pɹɑməs jə ɹivɛnʒ. ə loʊkeɪʃən. wɛɹ ɪz ʃi?"

Rand spoke to Kerb again. "I need a location," Rand said. "Something. If there is any vestige within you that resisted, any scrap that fought her, I promise you revenge. A location. Where is she?"

spɪɾəl dʒɹɪp fɹəm ðə bɔɪz lɪps. ðeɪ sim tə kwɪvɝ. ɹænd stʊɾ ʌp, lumɪŋ, stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ðə juθs aɪz wɪð ɪz oʊn. kɝb ʃɪvɝd, ðən wɪspɝd tu wɝdz.

Spittle dripped from the boy's lips. They seemed to quiver. Rand stood up, looming, still holding the youth's eyes with his own. Kerb shivered, then whispered two words.

"nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ."

"Natrin's Barrow."

ɹænd ɛksheɪl sɔfli, ðən ɹilis kɝb wɪð ən ɔlmoʊst ɹɛvɝən moʊʃən. ðə juθ slɪp fɹəm ðə bɛntʃ tə ðə flɔɹ, spɪɾəl dʒɹulɪŋ fɹəm ɪz lɪps ɑntu ðə ɹʌɡ. nɪneɪiv kɝst, lipɪŋ fɹəm əɹ sit, ðən wɑbəlɪŋ slaɪtli əz ðə ɹum spʌn. laɪt, ʃi wɑz ɪɡzɔstəd! ʃi stɛɾid hɝsɛlf, kloʊzd əɹ aɪz ən tʊk ə fju dip bɹɛθs. ðən ʃi nɛlt ət ðə bɔɪz saɪd.

Rand exhaled softly, then released Kerb with an almost reverent motion. The youth slipped from the bench to the floor, spittle drooling from his lips onto the rug. Nynaeve cursed, leaping from her seat, then wobbling slightly as the room spun. Light, she was exhausted! She steadied herself, closed her eyes and took a few deep breaths. Then she knelt at the boy's side.

"ju nidn bɑðɝ," ɹænd sɛd. "hi ɪz dɛd."

"You needn't bother," Rand said. "He is dead."

nɪneɪiv kənfɝm ðə dɛθ fəɹ hɝsɛlf. ðən ʃi snæpt əɹ hɛɾ ʌp, lʊkɪŋ ət ɹænd. wʌt ɹaɪt dɪɾ i hæv tə lʊk əz ɪɡzɔstəɾ əz ʃi fɛlt? hi hæd dʌn bɛɹli ɛniθɪŋ! "wʌt dɪd jə - "

Nynaeve confirmed the death for herself. Then she snapped her head up, looking at Rand. What right did he have to look as exhausted as she felt? He had done barely anything! "What did you - "

"aɪ dɪd nʌθɪŋ, nɪneɪiv. aɪ səspɛk ðət wʌns jə ɹimuv ðət kəmpʌlʃən, ði oʊnli θɪŋ kipɪŋ ɪm əlaɪv wɑz ɪz æŋɡɝ ət ɡɹeɪndəl, bɛɹid dipli. wʌtɛvɝ bɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf ɹɪmeɪnd, ɪt nu ði oʊnli hɛlp ɪt kəd ɡɪv wɝ ðoʊz tu wɝdz. æftɝ ðæt, hi dʒʌs lɛt ɡoʊ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ wi kəd də fəɹ hɪm."

"I did nothing, Nynaeve. I suspect that once you removed that Compulsion, the only thing keeping him alive was his anger at Graendal, buried deeply. Whatever bit of himself remained, it knew the only help it could give were those two words. After that, he just let go. There was nothing more we could do for him."

"aɪ doʊn æksɛp ðæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd. "hi cʊɾə bɪn hild!" ʃi ʃʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə hɛlp hɪm! ənduɪŋ ɡɹeɪndəlz kəmpʌlʃən hæd fɛl soʊ ɡʊd, soʊ ɹaɪt. ɪt ʃʊdn əv ɛndəd ðɪs weɪ!

"I don't accept that," Nynaeve said, frustrated. "He could have been Healed!" She should have been able to help him! Undoing Graendal's Compulsion had felt so good, so right. It shouldn't have ended this way!

ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd, filɪŋ dɝɾid. juzd. haʊ wɑz ʃi bɛɾɝ ðən ðə dʒeɪlɝ u hæd dʌn sətʃ hɔɹəbəl θɪŋz fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən? ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ɹænd. hi cʊɾə toʊld əɹ wʌt ɹimuvɪŋ kəmpʌlʃən wəd du!

She shuddered, feeling dirtied. Used. How was she better than the jailer who had done such horrible things for information? She glared at Rand. He could have told her what removing Compulsion would do!

"doʊn lʊk ət mi laɪk ðæt, nɪneɪiv." hi wɔk tə ðə dɔɹ ən dʒɛstʃɝd fəɹ ðə meɪɾənz ðəɹ tə kəlɛkt kɝbz bɑɾi. ðeɪ dɪd soʊ, kæɹiɪŋ ɪɾ əweɪ əz ɹænd kɔl sɔfli fəɹ ə nu pɑɾ ə ti.

"Don't look at me like that, Nynaeve." He walked to the door and gestured for the Maidens there to collect Kerb's body. They did so, carrying it away as Rand called softly for a new pot of tea.

hi ɹɪtɝnd, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə bɛntʃ bɪsaɪd ðə slipɪŋ mɪn; ʃid tʌkt wʌn ə ðə bɛntʃəz pɪloʊz ʌndɝ əɹ hɛd. wʌn ə ðə tu læmps ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz bɝnɪŋ loʊ, ən ðət lɛft ɪz feɪs hæf ɪn ʃædoʊ. "ðɪs wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ ɪt kəɾ əv hæpənd," hi kəntɪnjud. "ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz. jə ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪz ðət nɑt wʌn ə jəɹ kɹidz?"

He returned, sitting down on the bench beside the sleeping Min; she'd tucked one of the bench's pillows under her head. One of the two lamps in the room was burning low, and that left his face half in shadow. "This was the only way it could have happened," he continued. "The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills. You are Aes Sedai. Is that not one of your creeds?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz," nɪneɪiv snæpt, "bʌɾ ɪts nɑɾ ən ɪkskjus fəɹ jəɹ ækʃənz."

"I don't know what it is," Nynaeve snapped, "but it's not an excuse for your actions."

"wʌɾ ækʃənz?" hi æskt. "ju bɹɔt ðɪs mæn tə mi. ɡɹeɪndəl juz kəmpʌlʃən ɑn hɪm. naʊ əl kɪl əɹ fəɹ ɪt - ðəɾ ækʃən wɪl bi maɪ soʊl ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. naʊ, lemi bi. aɪ ʃæl tʃɹaɪ tə ɡoʊ bæk tə slip."

"What actions?" he asked. "You brought this man to me. Graendal used Compulsion on him. Now I will kill her for it - that action will be my sole responsibility. Now, let me be. I shall try to go back to sleep."

"doʊn jə fil ɛni ɡɪlt əɾ ɔl?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

"Don't you feel any guilt at all?" she demanded.

ðeɪ lɑkt aɪz, nɪneɪiv fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd ən hɛlpləs, ɹænd. . . . hu kəd ɡɛs wʌt ɹænd fɛl ðiz deɪz!

They locked eyes, Nynaeve frustrated and helpless, Rand. . . . Who could guess what Rand felt these days!

"ʃʊɾ aɪ sʌfɝ fəɹ əm ɔl, nɪneɪiv?" hi æskt kwaɪətli, ɹaɪzɪŋ, feɪs stɪl hæf ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs.

"Should I suffer for them all, Nynaeve?" he asked quietly, rising, face still half in the darkness.

"leɪ ðɪs dɛθ ət maɪ fit, ɪf jə wɪʃ. ɪɾəl dʒʌs bi wʌn ə mɛni. haʊ mɛni stoʊnz kən jə paɪl ɑn ə mænz bɑɾi bɪfɔɹ ðə weɪt stɑps mæɾɝɪŋ? haʊ fɑɹ kən jə bɝn ə lʌmp ə flɛʃ əntɪl fɝðɝ hiɾ ɪz ɪɹɛləvənt? ɪf aɪ lɛt maɪsɛlf fil ɡɪl fəɹ ðɪs bɔɪ, ðən aɪ wəd nid tə fil ɡɪl fəɹ ði ʌðɝz. ən ɪt wəd kɹʌʃ mi."

"Lay this death at my feet, if you wish. It will just be one of many. How many stones can you pile on a man's body before the weight stops mattering? How far can you burn a lump of flesh until further heat is irrelevant? If I let myself feel guilt for this boy, then I would need to feel guilt for the others. And it would crush me."

ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm ɪn ðə hæf laɪt. ə kɪŋ, sɝɾənli. ə soʊlʒɝ, ðoʊ hi hæɾ oʊnli əkeɪʒənəli sin wɔɹ. ʃi fɔɹs daʊn əɹ æŋɡɝ. hædn ðɪs ɔl bɪn əbaʊt pɹuvɪŋ tə hɪm ðəɾ i kəd tʃɹʌs hɝ?

She regarded him in the half light. A king, certainly. A soldier, though he had only occasionally seen war. She forced down her anger. Hadn't this all been about proving to him that he could trust her?

"oʊ, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. "ðɪs θɪŋ juv bɪkʌm, ðə hɑɹt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ɪmoʊʃən bʌɾ æŋɡɝ. ɪɾəl dɪstʃɹɔɪ ju."

"Oh, Rand," she said, turning away. "This thing you have become, the heart without any emotion but anger. It will destroy you."

"jɛs," hi sɛd sɔfli.

"Yes," he said softly.

ʃi lʊk bæk ət hɪm, ʃɑkt.

She looked back at him, shocked.

"aɪ kəntɪnju tə wʌndɝ," hi sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ daʊn ət mɪn, "waɪ jə ɔl əsum ðəɾ aɪm tu dɛns tə si wʌt jə faɪn soʊ ɑbviəs. jɛs, nɪneɪiv. jɛs, ðɪs hɑɹdnəs wɪl dɪstʃɹɔɪ mi. aɪ noʊ."

"I continue to wonder," he said, glancing down at Min, "why you all assume that I am too dense to see what you find so obvious. Yes, Nynaeve. Yes, this hardness will destroy me. I know."

"ðɛn waɪ?" ʃi æskt. "waɪ woʊn jə lɛɾ əs hɛlp ju?"

"Then why?" she asked. "Why won't you let us help you?"

hi lʊkt ʌp - nɑɾ ət hɝ, bʌt stɛɹɪŋ ɔf ət nʌθɪŋ. ə sɝvənt nɑkt kwaɪətli, wɛɹɪŋ ðə waɪɾ ən fɔɹəst ɡɹin ə maɪləsɹz haʊs. ʃi ɛntɝɾ ən dəpɑzɪɾɪd ðə nu pɑɾ ə ti, pɪkt ʌp ði oʊld wʌn, ðən wɪθdʒɹu.

He looked up - not at her, but staring off at nothing. A servant knocked quietly, wearing the white and forest green of Milisair's house. She entered and deposited the new pot of tea, picked up the old one, then withdrew.

"wɛn aɪ wɑz mʌtʃ jʌŋɡɝ," hi sɛd, vɔɪs sɑft, "tæm toʊl mi ʌv ə stɔɹi hid hɝd waɪl tʃɹævlɪŋ ðə wɝld. hi spoʊk ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. aɪ dɪdnt noʊ ət ðə taɪm ðət hiɾ æktʃəli  sin ɪt, nɔɹ ðəɾ i hæd faʊn mi ðɛɹ. aɪ wɑz dʒʌst ə ʃɛpɝd bɔɪ, ən dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, tɑɹ vəlɑn ən keɪɛmlɪn wɝ ɔlmoʊs mɪθəkəl pleɪsəz tə mi.

"When I was much younger," he said, voice soft, "Tam told me of a story he'd heard while traveling the world. He spoke of Dragonmount. I didn't know at the time that he'd actually seen it, nor that he had found me there. I was just a shepherd boy, and Dragonmount, Tar Valon and Caemlyn were almost mythical places to me.

"hi toʊl mi ʌv ɪt, ðoʊ, ə maʊntən soʊ haɪ ɪt meɪɾ ivən twɪnhɔɝnz pik bæk hoʊm sim ə dwɔɹf. tæmz stɔɹiz kleɪm noʊ mæn hæɾ ɛvɝ klaɪm tə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊns pik. nɑt kəz ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl - bʌt kəz ɹitʃɪŋ ðə tɑp wəd teɪk ɛvɹi læst aʊns ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə mæn hæd. soʊ tɔl wɑz ðə maʊntən ðət bɛstɪŋ ɪt wəd bi ə stʃɹʌɡəl ðət dʒɹeɪn ə mæn kəmplitli."

"He told me of it, though, a mountain so high it made even Twinhorn's Peak back home seem a dwarf. Tam's stories claimed no man had ever climbed to Dragonmount's peak. Not because it was impossible - but because reaching the top would take every last ounce of strength a man had. So tall was the mountain that besting it would be a struggle that drained a man completely."

hi fɛl saɪlənt.

He fell silent.

"soʊ?" nɪneɪiv faɪnəli æskt.

"So?" Nynaeve finally asked.

hi lʊkt ət hɝ. "doʊn jə si? ðə stɔɹiz kleɪm noʊ mæn hæd klaɪm ðə maʊntən kəz ɪn duɪŋ soʊ, hi wəd bi wɪθaʊt stʃɹɛŋkθ tə ɹɪtɝn. ə maʊntɪnɪɹ kəd bɛst ɪt, ɹitʃ ðə tɑp, si wʌt noʊ mæn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. bʌt ðən i wəd daɪ. ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ən waɪzəst ɪksplɔɹɝz nu ðɪs. soʊ ðeɪ nɛvɝ klaɪmd ɪt. ðeɪ ɔlweɪz wɑntəd tə, bʌt ðeɪ weɪɾəd, ɹɪzɝvɪŋ ðət tʃɹɪp fəɹ ənʌðɝ deɪ. fəɹ ðeɪ nu ɪt wəd bi ðɛɹ læst."

He looked at her. "Don't you see? The stories claimed no man had climbed the mountain because in doing so, he would be without strength to return. A mountaineer could best it, reach the top, see what no man had ever seen. But then he would die. The strongest and wisest explorers knew this. So they never climbed it. They always wanted to, but they waited, reserving that trip for another day. For they knew it would be their last."

"bʌt ðæts dʒʌst ə stɔɹi," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ə lɛdʒənd."

"But that's just a story," Nynaeve said. "A legend."

"ðæts wʌɾ aɪ æm," ɹænd sɛd. "ə stɔɹi. ə lɛdʒənd. tə bi toʊl tə tʃɪlʒɹən jɪɹz fɹəm naʊ, spoʊkən ʌv ɪn wɪspɝz." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "səmtaɪmz, jə kæn tɝn bæk. juv tə kip pɹɛsɪŋ ɑn.

"That's what I am," Rand said. "A story. A legend. To be told to children years from now, spoken of in whispers." He shook his head. "Sometimes, you can't turn back. You have to keep pressing on.

ən səmtaɪmz, jə noʊ ðɪs klaɪm ɪz jəɹ læst.

And sometimes, you know this climb is your last.

"ju ɔl kleɪm ðəɾ aɪ hæv ɡɹoʊn tu hɑɹd, ðəɾ əl ɪnɛvəɾəbli ʃæɾɝ ən bɹeɪk ɪf aɪ kəntɪnju ɑn.

"You all claim that I have grown too hard, that I will inevitably shatter and break if I continue on.

bʌt jə əsum ðət ðəɹ nidz tə bi sʌmθɪŋ lɛft ə mi tə kəntɪnju ɑn. ðəɾ aɪ nid tə klaɪm bæk daʊn ðə maʊntən wʌns aɪv ɹitʃt ðə tɑp.

But you assume that there needs to be something left of me to continue on. That I need to climb back down the mountain once I've reached the top.

"ðæts ðə ki, nɪneɪiv. aɪ si ɪt naʊ. əl nɑt lɪv θɹu ðɪs, ən soʊ aɪ doʊnt nid tə wɝi əbaʊt wʌt maɪt hæpən tə mi æftɝ ðə læs bæɾəl. aɪ doʊnt nid tə hoʊl bæk, doʊnt nid tə sælvədʒ ɛniθɪŋ ə ðɪs biɾən ʌp soʊl ə maɪn. aɪ noʊ ðəɾ aɪ mʌs daɪ. ðoʊz u wɪʃ fəɹ mi tə bi sɑftɝ, wɪlɪŋ tə bɛnd, ɑɹ ðoʊz u kænɑɾ æksɛpt wʌt wɪl hæpən tə mi." hi lʊk daʊn ət mɪn əɡɛn.

"That's the key, Nynaeve. I see it now. I will not live through this, and so I don't need to worry about what might happen to me after the Last Battle. I don't need to hold back, don't need to salvage anything of this beaten up soul of mine. I know that I must die. Those who wish for me to be softer, willing to bend, are those who cannot accept what will happen to me." He looked down at Min again.

mɛni taɪmz bɪfɔɹ, nɪneɪiv hæd sin əfɛkʃən ɪn ɪz aɪz wən i ɹəɡɑɹɾəd hɝ, bʌt ðɪs taɪm ðeɪ wɝ blæŋk. sɛɾ ɪn ðət seɪm, ɪmoʊʃənləs feɪs.

Many times before, Nynaeve had seen affection in his eyes when he regarded her, but this time they were blank. Set in that same, emotionless face.

"wi kən faɪn ə weɪ, ɹænd," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ʃʊɹli ðəɹ ɪz ə weɪ tə wɪn bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ lɛt jə lɪv."

"We can find a way, Rand," Nynaeve said. "Surely there is a way to win but also let you live."

"noʊ," hi ɡɹaʊl sɔfli. "du nɑt tɛmp mi daʊn ðət pæθ əɡɛn. ɪɾ oʊnli lidz tə peɪn, nɪneɪiv.

"No," he growled softly. "Do not tempt me down that path again. It only leads to pain, Nynaeve.

aɪ . . . aɪ juz tə θɪŋk əbaʊt livɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ bɪhaɪn tə hɛlp ðə wɝl sɝvaɪv wʌns aɪ daɪd, bʌt ðət wɑz ə stʃɹʌɡəl tə kip lɪvɪŋ. aɪ kæn ɪndʌlʒ maɪsɛlf. əl klaɪm ðɪs blʌɾi maʊntən ən feɪs ðə sʌn.

I . . . I used to think about leaving something behind to help the world survive once I died, but that was a struggle to keep living. I can't indulge myself. I'll climb this bloody mountain and face the sun.

jə ɔl wɪl dil wɪð wʌt kʌmz nɛkst. ðəɾ ɪz haʊ ɪt mʌs bi."

You all will deal with what comes next. That is how it must be."

ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə əbdʒɛkt əɡɛn, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv əɹ ə ʃɑɹp ɡlæns. "ðæɾ ɪz haʊ ɪt mʌs bi, nɪneɪiv."

She opened her mouth to object again, but he gave her a sharp glance. "That is how it must be, Nynaeve."

ʃi kloʊzd əɹ maʊθ.

She closed her mouth.

"ju dɪd wɛl tənaɪt," ɹænd sɛd. "ju hæv seɪvd əs ɔl ə lɑɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl."

"You did well tonight," Rand said. "You have saved us all a lot of trouble."

"aɪ dɪɾ ɪt kəz aɪ wɑn jə tə tʃɹʌs mi," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ðən ɪmiɾiətli kɝs hɝsɛlf. waɪ hæd ʃi sɛd ðæt? wɑz ʃi ɹɪli soʊ taɪɝd ðət ʃi blæb ðə fɝs θɪŋ ðət keɪm tə hɝ maɪnd?

"I did it because I want you to trust me," Nynaeve said, then immediately cursed herself. Why had she said that? Was she really so tired that she blabbed the first thing that came to her mind?

ɹænd dʒʌs nɑɾəd. "aɪ də tʃɹʌs ju, nɪneɪiv. əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ tʃɹʌst ɛniwʌn; mɔɹ ðən aɪ tʃɹʌs moʊst. jə θɪŋk jə noʊ wʌɾ ɪz bɛs fəɹ mi, ivən əɡɛns maɪ wɪʃɪz, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ aɪ kən æksɛpt. ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin jə ən kædzueɪn ɪz ðət jə æktʃəli  kɛɹ əbaʊt mi. ʃi oʊnli kɛɹz əbaʊt maɪ pleɪs ɪn əɹ plænz. ʃi wɑns mi tə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə læs bæɾəl. jə wɑn mi tə lɪv. fəɹ juv hæv maɪ θæŋks. dʒɹim ɑn maɪ bɪhæf, nɪneɪiv. dʒɹim fəɹ θɪŋz aɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kæn."

Rand just nodded. "I do trust you, Nynaeve. As much as I trust anyone; more than I trust most. You think you know what is best for me, even against my wishes, but that is something I can accept. The difference between you and Cadsuane is that you actually care about me. She only cares about my place in her plans. She wants me to be part of the Last Battle. You want me to live. For that, you have my thanks. Dream on my behalf, Nynaeve. Dream for things I no longer can."

hi lin daʊn tə pɪk ʌp mɪn; hi mænədʒd ɪt dɪspaɪɾ ɪz mɪsɪŋ hænd, sneɪkɪŋ wʌn ɑɹm ʌndɝniθ əɹ ən ɡɹɪpɪŋ wɪð ɪz hæn əz i lɪftəɾ əɹ ʌp. ʃi stɝd, ðən snʌɡəld ɪn kloʊs tə hɪm, weɪkɪŋ ən mɝmɝɪŋ ə kəmpleɪn ðət ʃi kəd wɔk. hi dɪdn pʊɾ əɹ daʊn; pɝhæps kəz ə ði ɪɡzɔstʃən ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. nɪneɪiv nu ʃi steɪɾ ʌp wɪð əɹ bʊks moʊs naɪts, pʊʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɔlmoʊst əz hɑɹɾ əz ɹænd dɪd.

He leaned down to pick up Min; he managed it despite his missing hand, snaking one arm underneath her and gripping with his hand as he lifted her up. She stirred, then snuggled in close to him, waking and murmuring a complaint that she could walk. He didn't put her down; perhaps because of the exhaustion in her voice. Nynaeve knew she stayed up with her books most nights, pushing herself almost as hard as Rand did.

kæɹiɪŋ mɪn, hi wɔk təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ. "wi wɪl dil wɪð ðə sintʃæn fɝst," hi sɛd. "bi wɛl pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ðət miɾɪŋ. əl teɪk kɛɹ ʌv ɡɹeɪndəl sun æftɝ."

Carrying Min, he walked toward the door. "We will deal with the Seanchan first," he said. "Be well prepared for that meeting. I will take care of Graendal soon after."

hi lɛft əɹ ðɛn. ðə flɪkɝɪŋ læmp faɪnəli ɡeɪv aʊt, livɪŋ oʊnli ðə wʌn ɑn ðə teɪbəl.

He left her then. The flickering lamp finally gave out, leaving only the one on the table.

ɹænd hæd sɝpɹaɪzd əɹ əɡɛn. hi wɑz stɪl ə wʊl-hɛɾəd ful, bʌɾ i wɑz ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli sɛlf- əwɛɹ wʌn. haʊ kəɾ ə mæn ʌndɝstæn soʊ mʌtʃ, jɛt stɪl bi soʊ ɪɡnɝənt?

Rand had surprised her again. He was still a wool-headed fool, but he was a surprisingly self- aware one. How could a man understand so much, yet still be so ignorant?

ən waɪ kʊdnt ʃi kʌm ʌp wɪð ən ɑɹɡjəmən əɡɛnst wʌt hid sɛd? waɪ kʊdnt ʃi meɪk hɝsɛlf jɛl əɾ ɪm ðəɾ i wɑz ɹɔŋ? ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz hoʊp. baɪ sɝɛndɝɪŋ ðət moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪmoʊʃən, hi maɪt meɪk hɪmsɛlf stʃɹɔŋ - bʌt ɹɪsk luzɪŋ ɔl ɹizən i maɪɾ əv tə kɛɹ əbaʊt ði aʊtkʌm ə hɪz bæɾəlz.

And why couldn't she come up with an argument against what he'd said? Why couldn't she make herself yell at him that he was wrong? There was always hope. By surrendering that most important emotion, he might make himself strong - but risked losing all reason he might have to care about the outcome of his battles.

fəɹ səm ɹizən, ʃi kʊdn faɪnd wɝdz fəɹ ði ɑɹɡjəmənt.

For some reason, she couldn't find words for the argument.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾifɔɹ

CHAPTER 34

lɛdʒənz "ɔl ɹaɪt," mæt sɛd, ənɹoʊlɪŋ wʌn ə ɹɔɪdɛlz bɛs mæps ɑn ɪz teɪbəl. tælmɑnz, tɑm, noʊl, dʒulɪn ən mændəvwɪn hæɾ ɝeɪnʒd ðɛɹ tʃɛɹz ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl. bɪsaɪd ðə mæp ə ði ɛɹiə, mæt ənɹoʊld ə skɛtʃ ə ðə leɪaʊɾ ʌv ə miɾiəm-saɪzd taʊn. ɪt hæd teɪkən səm duɪŋ tə faɪn ə mɝtʃənt wɪlɪŋ tə skɛtʃ əm ə mæp ə tʃɹʌstɛɹ, bʌɾ æftɝ hɪndɝstæp, mæt dɪdn laɪk tə ɡoʊ ɪndə ə taʊn wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ʌp əɡɛnst.

Legends "All right," Mat said, unrolling one of Roidelle's best maps on his table. Talmanes, Thom, Noal, Juilin and Mandevwin had arranged their chairs around the table. Beside the map of the area, Mat unrolled a sketch of the layout of a medium-sized town. It had taken some doing to find a merchant willing to sketch them a map of Trustair, but after Hinderstap, Mat didn't like to go into a town without knowing what they were up against.

mæts pəvɪljən wɑz ʃeɪɾɪd baɪ ðə paɪn fɔɹəst aʊtsaɪd, ən ðə deɪ wɑz kul. əkeɪʒənəli, ðə wɪnd wəd bloʊ, ən ə smɔl spɹɪŋkəl ə dɛd paɪn niɾəlz wəd ʃeɪk fɹi fɹəm ðə baʊz əbʌv ən fɔl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, səm skɹætʃɪŋ ðə tɑp ə ðə tɛn əz ðeɪ fɛl. aʊtsaɪd, soʊlʒɝz kɔl tə wʌn ənʌðɝ ən pɑts klæŋd əz ðə mɪddeɪ mil wɑz dɪstʃɹɪbjəɾəd.

Mat's pavilion was shaded by the pine forest outside, and the day was cool. Occasionally, the wind would blow, and a small sprinkle of dead pine needles would shake free from the boughs above and fall to the ground, some scratching the top of the tent as they fell. Outside, soldiers called to one another and pots clanged as the midday meal was distributed.

mæt stʌɾid ðə taʊn mæp. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə stɑp biɪŋ ə ful. ðə hoʊl wɝl hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tɝn əɡɛnst ɪm - ivən ɹʊɹəl maʊntən taʊnz wɝ dɛθ tʃɹæps, ðiz deɪz. nɛkst i nu, ðə deɪziz ɑn ðə saɪdz ə ðə ɹoʊd wəd bi ɡæŋɪŋ ʌp tə tʃɹaɪ ən it hɪm.

Mat studied the town map. It was time to stop being a fool. The whole world had decided to turn against him - even rural mountain towns were death traps, these days. Next he knew, the daisies on the sides of the road would be ganging up to try and eat him.

ðət θɔt ɡeɪv ɪm pɔz əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə pʊɹ pɛdlɝ, sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə ðə fæntəm ʃiəɾən taʊn. wən ðət ɡoʊsli pleɪs hæd vænɪʃt, ɪt hæd lɛf bɪhaɪn ə mɛdoʊ wɪð bʌɾɝflaɪz ən flaʊɝz.

That thought gave him pause as he remembered the poor peddler, sinking into the phantom Shiotan town. When that ghostly place had vanished, it had left behind a meadow with butterflies and flowers.

ɪnkluɾɪŋ deɪziz. bɝn mi, hi θɔt.

Including daisies. Burn me, he thought.

wɛl, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən wɑzn əbaʊt tə ɛn ʌp dɛɾ ɑn səm ɹændəm bækwɔɾɝ ɹoʊd. ðɪs taɪm i wəd plæn ən i wəd bi ɹɛɾi. hi nɑɾəd tə hɪmsɛlf ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən.

Well, Matrim Cauthon wasn't about to end up dead on some random backwater road. This time he would plan and he would be ready. He nodded to himself in satisfaction.

"ði ɪn ɪz hɪɹ," mæt sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə taʊn mæp. "ðə ʃeɪkən fɪst. tu sɛpɹət tʃɹævəlɝz əɡɹid ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə faɪn ɪn, ðə naɪsɪst ə ðə θɹi ɪn ðə taʊn. ðə wʊmən lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi hæzən meɪɾ ɛni ɛfɝt tə haɪɾ əɹ wɛɹəbaʊts, soʊ ðət minz ʃi θɪŋks ðət ʃiz wɛl pɹətɛktəd. wi kən ɪkspɛkt ɡɑɹdz."

"The inn is here," Mat said, pointing at the town map. "The Shaken Fist. Two separate travelers agreed that it was a fine inn, the nicest of the three in the town. The woman looking for me hasn't made any effort to hide her whereabouts, so that means she thinks that she is well protected. We can expect guards."

mæt pʊld aʊɾ ənʌðɝ ə ɹɔɪdɛlz mæps, wʌn ðət bɛɾɝ ʃoʊd ðə dʒiɑɡɹəfi ɝaʊn tʃɹʌstɛɹ.

Mat pulled out another of Roidelle's maps, one that better showed the geography around Trustair.

ðə taʊn sæɾ ɪn ə smɔl hɑloʊ, sɝaʊndəd baɪ dʒɛnli ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl leɪk fɛd baɪ haɪlən spɹɪŋz. ðə leɪk ɹɪpɔɹɾədli pɹədust səm faɪn tʃɹaʊt, ðə sɔltɪŋ ʌv wɪtʃ wɑz ðə taʊnz meɪn tʃɹeɪd.

The town sat in a small hollow, surrounded by gently rolling hills beside a small lake fed by highland springs. The lake reportedly produced some fine trout, the salting of which was the town's main trade.

"aɪ wɑn θɹi skwɑdz ə laɪt kævəlɹi hɪɹ," mæt sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ əɾ ən ʌpɝ sloʊp. "ðeɪl bi hɪɾən baɪ ðə tʃɹiz, bʌt wɪl əv fʊl vju ʌv ðə skaɪz. ɪf ə ɹɛd naɪtfloʊɝ ɡoʊz ʌp, ðəɹ tə kʌm ɪn dɝɛkli əlɔŋ ðə meɪn ɹoʊd hɪɹ fəɹ ə ɹɛskju. wɪl əv ə hʌnʒɹəd kɹɔsboʊmən sɪkwɛstɝɾ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə taʊn əz ə bækʌp tə ðə kævəlɹi. ɪf ðə naɪtfloʊɝ ɪz ɡɹin ɪnstɛd, ðə kævəlɹi ɪz tə mɑɹtʃ ɪn ən sɪkjʊɹ ðə meɪn ɹoʊdz tə ðə taʊn, hɪɹ, hɪɹ ən hɪɹ."

"I want three squads of light cavalry here," Mat said, pointing at an upper slope. "They'll be hidden by the trees, but will have full view of the skies. If a red nightflower goes up, they're to come in directly along the main road here for a rescue. We'll have a hundred crossbowmen sequestered on either side of the town as a backup to the cavalry. If the nightflower is green instead, the cavalry is to march in and secure the main roads to the town, here, here and here."

mæt lʊkt ʌp, pɔɪntɪŋ ət tɑm. "tɑm, jəl teɪk hɑɹnən, fɝdʒɪn ən mændəvwɪn əz 'əpɹɛntəsɪz' ən noʊl kən bi jəɹ fʊtmən."

Mat looked up, pointing at Thom. "Thom, you'll take Harnan, Fergin and Mandevwin as 'apprentices' and Noal can be your footman."

"fʊtmən?" noʊl æskt. hi wɑz ə nɑɹl mæn, mɪsɪŋ tiθ, wɪð ə hʊk bik ʌv ə noʊz. bʌɾ i wɑz tʌf əz ən oʊld, bæɾəl-skɔɹd sɔɹd pæs daʊn fɹəm fɑðɝ tə sʌn. "waɪ dʌz ə ɡlimən niɾ ə fʊtmən?"

"Footman?" Noal asked. He was a gnarled man, missing teeth, with a hooked beak of a nose. But he was tough as an old, battle-scored sword passed down from father to son. "Why does a gleeman need a footman?"

"ɔl ɹaɪt," mæt sɛd. "ju kən bi hɪz bɹʌðɝ ðɛn, hu dʌbəlz əz ə mænsɝvənt. dʒulɪn, jə - "

"All right," Mat said. "You can be his brother then, who doubles as a manservant. Juilin, you - "

"weɪt, mæt," mændəvwɪn sɛd, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz feɪs nɪɹ ɪz aɪ pætʃ. "aɪm tə bi ən əpɹɛntəs ɡlimən? aɪm nɑt sɝɾən maɪ vɔɪs ɪz suɾəd tə faɪn sɪŋɪŋ. juv hɝd mi, aɪ wɔɹənt. ən wɪð oʊnli wʌn aɪ, aɪ daʊɾ əl fɛɹ wɛl ət dʒʌɡəlɪŋ."

"Wait, Mat," Mandevwin said, scratching his face near his eye patch. "I'm to be an apprentice gleeman? I'm not certain my voice is suited to fine singing. You've heard me, I warrant. And with only one eye, I doubt I'll fare well at juggling."

"jɔɹ ə nu əpɹɛntəs," mæt sɛd. "tɑm noʊz jə doʊn əv ɛni tælənt, bʌɾ i tʊk pɪɾi ɑn jə kəz jəɹ ɡɹeɪt-ænt - wɪð hum juv lɪv sɪns jəɹ pɛɹəns daɪɾ ɪn ə tʃɹædʒɪk ɑksən stæmpid - tʊk sɪk ə ðə kloʊvɝ pɑks ən wɛn kɹeɪzi. ʃi stɑɹɾəd fiɾɪŋ jə teɪbəl skɹæps ən tʃɹiɾəd jə laɪk ðə fæmli haʊnd, mɑɹks, hud ɹʌn əweɪ wən jə wɝ dʒʌst sɛvən."

"You're a new apprentice," Mat said. "Thom knows you don't have any talent, but he took pity on you because your great-aunt - with whom you've lived since your parents died in a tragic oxen stampede - took sick of the clover pox and went crazy. She started feeding you table scraps and treated you like the family hound, Marks, who'd run away when you were just seven."

mændəvwɪn skɹætʃt ɪz hɛd. hɪz hɛɹ wɑz stʃɹikt wɪð ɡɹeɪ. "ɑɹən aɪ ə lɪɾəl oʊl tə bi ən əpɹɛntəs, ðoʊ?"

Mandevwin scratched his head. His hair was streaked with gray. "Aren't I a little old to be an apprentice, though?"

"nɑnsɛns," mæt sɛd. "jɔɹ jʌŋ ət hɑɹt, ən sɪns jə nɛvɝ mɛɹid - ði oʊnli wʊmən jə ɛvɝ lʌvd ɹæn əweɪ wɪð ðə tænɝz sʌn - tɑmz ɝaɪvəl ɔfɝd jə ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə stɑɹt fɹɛʃ."

"Nonsense," Mat said. "You're young at heart, and since you never married - the only woman you ever loved ran away with the tanner's son - Thom's arrival offered you an opportunity to start fresh."

"bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt wɑnə liv maɪ ɡɹeɪt-ænt," mændəvwɪn pɹətɛstəd. "ʃiz kɛɹd fəɹ mi sɪns aɪ wɑz ə tʃaɪld! ɪts nɑɾ ɑnəst ʌv ə mæn tə əbændən ən ɛldɝli wʊmən dʒʌs kəz ʃi ɡɛts ə lɪɾəl kənfjuzd."

"But I don't want to leave my great-aunt," Mandevwin protested. "She's cared for me since I was a child! It's not honest of a man to abandon an elderly woman just because she gets a little confused."

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɡɹeɪt-ænt," mæt sɛd wɪð ɛksæspɝeɪʃən. "ðɪs ɪz dʒʌst ə lɛdʒənd, ə stɔɹi tə ɡoʊ wɪð jəɹ fɔls neɪm."

"There is no great-aunt," Mat said with exasperation. "This is just a legend, a story to go with your false name."

"kæn aɪ hæv ə stɔɹi ðət meɪks mi mɔɹ ɑnɝəbəl?" mændəvwɪn æskt.

"Can't I have a story that makes me more honorable?" Mandevwin asked.

"tu leɪt," mæt sɛd, ɹaɪflɪŋ θɹu ə stæk ɑn ɪz dɛsk, sɝtʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə klʌstɝ ə faɪv peɪdʒəz kʌvɝɾ ɪn skɹɔl hændʒɹaɪɾɪŋ. "ju kæn tʃeɪnʒ naʊ. aɪ spɛn hæf ðə naɪt wɝkɪŋ ɑn jəɹ stɔɹi. ɪts ðə bɛst aʊɾ ə ðə lɑt. hɪɹ, mɛmɝaɪz ðɪs." hi hændəɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ tə mændəvwɪn, ðən ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ənʌðɝ stæk ə peɪpɝz ən bɪɡæn lʊkɪŋ θɹu ðɛm.

"Too late," Mat said, rifling through a stack on his desk, searching out a cluster of five pages covered in scrawled handwriting. "You can't change now. I spent half the night working on your story. It's the best out of the lot. Here, memorize this." He handed it over to Mandevwin, then got out another stack of papers and began looking through them.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ wɝ nɑt teɪkɪŋ ðɪs ə lɪɾəl tu fɑɹ, læd?" tɑm æskt.

"Are you sure we're not taking this a little too far, lad?" Thom asked.

"aɪm nɑt gɑnə bi sɝpɹaɪzd əɡɛn, tɑm," mæt sɛd. "bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪm nɑt gɑnə lɛɾ ɪt hæpən. aɪm taɪɝɾ ʌv wɔkɪŋ ɪndə tʃɹæps ʌnpɹipɛɹd. aɪ plæn tə teɪk kəmæn ə maɪ oʊn dɛstəni, stɑp ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm pɹɑbləm tə pɹɑbləm. ɪts taɪm tə bi ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ."

"I'm not going to be surprised again, Thom," Mat said. "Burn me, but I'm not going to let it happen. I'm tired of walking into traps unprepared. I plan to take command of my own destiny, stop running from problem to problem. It's time to be in charge."

"æn jə də ðət wɪð . . ." dʒulɪn sɛd.

"And you do that with . . ." Julin said.

"ɪlæbɹəɾ eɪliəsɪz wɪð bækstɔɹiz," mæt sɛd, hændɪŋ tɑm ən noʊl ðɛɹ ʃits. "blʌɾi ɹaɪɾ aɪ du."

"Elaborate aliases with backstories," Mat said, handing Thom and Noal their sheets. "Bloody right I do."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt mi?" tælmɑnz æskt. ðət twɪŋkəl tə hɪz aɪz wɑz bæk, ðoʊ hi spoʊk wɪð ə kəmplitli ɝnɪs vɔɪs. "lɛt mi ɡɛs, mæt. ɪm ə tʃɹævlɪŋ mɝtʃən u wʌns tʃɹeɪnd wɪð ði il ən u hæz kʌm tə ðə vɪlədʒ kəz hiz hɝd ðɛɹz ə tʃɹaʊt ðət laɪvz ɪn ðə leɪk u ɪnsʌltɪɾ ɪz fɑðɝ."

"What about me?" Talmanes asked. That twinkle to his eyes was back, though he spoke with a completely earnest voice. "Let me guess, Mat. I'm a traveling merchant who once trained with the Aiel and who has come to the village because he's heard there's a trout that lives in the lake who insulted his father."

"nɑnsɛns," mæt sɛd, hændɪŋ ɪm ɪz ʃits. "jɔɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ."

"Nonsense," Mat said, handing him his sheets. "You're a Warder."

"ðæts ɹæðɝ səspɪʃəs," tælmɑnz noʊɾəd.

"That's rather suspicious," Talmanes noted.

"jɔɹ səpoʊz tə bi səspɪʃəs," mæt sɛd. "ɪts ɔlweɪz iziɝ tə biɾ ə mæn ɪn kɑɹdz wən hiz θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. wɛl, jəl bi əɹ 'sʌmθɪŋ ɛls.' eɪ wɔɹɾɝ pæsɪŋ θɹu taʊn ɑn mɪstɪɹiəs bɪznəs woʊn bi soʊ ɡɹæn ən ɪvɛn ðəɾ ɪɾəl dʒɹɔ tu mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən, bʌt tə ðoʊz u noʊ wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ, ɪɾəl bi ə ɡʊd dɪstʃɹækʃən. jə kən juz fɛnz kloʊk. hi sɛd hid lemi bɑɹoʊ ɪt; hi stɪl filz ɡɪlti fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ ðoʊz sɝvɪŋ wɪmən ɡɛɾ əweɪ."

"You're supposed to be suspicious," Mat said. "It's always easier to beat a man in cards when he's thinking about something else. Well, you'll be our 'something else.' A Warder passing through town on mysterious business won't be so grand an event that it will draw too much attention, but to those who know what to look for, it will be a good distraction. You can use Fen's cloak. He said he'd let me borrow it; he still feels guilty for letting those serving women get away."

"ʌv kɔɹs, jə dɪdn tɛl ɪm ðət ðeɪ sɪmpli vænɪʃt," tɑm æɾəd. "æn ðət ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ fəɹ ɪm tə kip ɪt fɹəm hæpənɪŋ."

"Of course, you didn't tell him that they simply vanished," Thom added. "And that there was no way for him to keep it from happening."

"dɪdn si ðə pɔɪn ə tɛlɪŋ hɪm," mæt sɛd. "noʊ jus dwɛlɪŋ ɑn ðə pæst, aɪ seɪ."

"Didn't see the point of telling him," Mat said. "No use dwelling on the past, I say."

"eɪ wɔɹɾɝ, ɪz ɪt?" tælmɑnz sɛd, flɪpɪŋ θɹu hɪz stæk ə peɪpɝz. "aɪl əv tə pɹæktəs skaʊlɪŋ."

"A Warder, is it?" Talmanes said, flipping through his stack of papers. "I'll have to practice scowling."

mæt ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm wɪð ə flæɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən. "jɔɹ nɑt teɪkɪŋ ðɪs sɪɹiəsli."

Mat regarded him with a flat expression. "You're not taking this seriously."

"wʌt dɪd jə æsk? ɪz ðəɹ sʌmwʌn u ɪz teɪkɪŋ ðɪs sɪɹiəsli?" bɝn ðət twɪŋkəl. hæd mæt ɹɪli ɛvɝ θɔt ðɪs mæn wɑz sloʊ tə læf? hi dʒʌs dɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn ði ɪnsaɪd. ðət wɑz ðə moʊst ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ weɪ.

"What did you ask? Is there someone who is taking this seriously?" Burn that twinkle. Had Mat really ever thought this man was slow to laugh? He just did it on the inside. That was the most infuriating way.

"laɪt, tælmɑnz," mæt sɛd. "ə wʊmən ɪn ðət taʊn ɪz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ pɛɹɪn ən mi. ʃi noʊz wʌt wi lʊk laɪk soʊ wɛl ðət ʃi kən pɹədus ə dʒɹɔɪŋ mɔɹ ækjɝət ðən maɪ oʊn mʌðɝ kəɾ əv meɪd. ðət ɡɪvz mi ə tʃɪl, laɪk ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf stændɪŋ oʊvɝ maɪ ʃoʊldɝ. ən aɪ kænt ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə fleɪmɪŋ pleɪs maɪsɛlf, sɪns ɛvɹi blʌɾi mæn, wʊmən ən tʃaɪld əz ə pɪktʃɝ wɪð maɪ feɪs ɑn ɪɾ ən ə pɹɑməs ʌv ɡoʊl fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən!

"Light, Talmanes," Mat said. "A woman in that town is looking for Perrin and me. She knows what we look like so well that she can produce a drawing more accurate than my own mother could have made. That gives me a chill, like the Dark One himself standing over my shoulder. And I can't go into the flaming place myself, since every bloody man, woman and child has a picture with my face on it and a promise of gold for information!

"naʊ meɪbi aɪ wɛn ə lɪɾəl fɑɹ wɪð ðə pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz, bʌɾ aɪ ɪntɛn tə faɪn ðɪs pɝsən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən ɔɹɾɝ ə flɑk ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz - əɹ wɝs - tə kʌt maɪ θɹoʊɾ ɪn ðə naɪt. ʌndɝstʊd?"

"Now maybe I went a little far with the preparations, but I intend to find this person before they can order a flock of Darkfriends - or worse - to cut my throat in the night. Understood?"

mæt lʊkt itʃ ə ðə faɪv mɛn ɪn ði aɪz, nɑɾəd, ən stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə tɛn flæp, bʌt pɔz bɪsaɪd tælmɑnzəz tʃɛɹ. mæt klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt, ðən hæf mʌmbəld, "ju sikɹɪtli hɑɹbɝ ə lʌv ə peɪntɪŋ, ən jə wɪʃ jə kəɾ ɪskeɪp ðɪs laɪf ə dɛθ juv kəmɪɾəd jɝsɛlf tə. jə keɪm θɹu tʃɹʌstɛɹ ɑn jəɹ weɪ saʊθ, ɹæðɝ ðən teɪkɪŋ ə mɔɹ dɝɛkt ɹut, kəz jə lʌv ðə maʊntənz. jəɹ hoʊpɪŋ tə hɪɹ wɝɾ ə jəɹ jʌŋɡɝ bɹʌðɝ, hum jə hævən sin ɪn jɪɹz, ən u dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɑn ə hʌntɪŋ tʃɹɪp ɪn sʌðɝn ændɝ. juv ə vɛɹi tɔɹtʃɝd pæst. ɹɛd peɪdʒ fɔɹ."

Mat looked each of the five men in the eyes, nodded, and started toward the tent flap, but paused beside Talmanes's chair. Mat cleared his throat, then half mumbled, "You secretly harbor a love of painting, and you wish you could escape this life of death you've committed yourself to. You came through Trustair on your way south, rather than taking a more direct route, because you love the mountains. You're hoping to hear word of your younger brother, whom you haven't seen in years, and who disappeared on a hunting trip in southern Andor. You have a very tortured past. Read page four."

mæt hɝiɾ ɑn, pʊʃɪŋ ɪz weɪ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ʃeɪɾɪd nun, ðoʊ hi dɪd kætʃ ə ɡlɪmps ə tælmɑnz ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪz aɪz. bɝn ðə mæn! ðəɹ wɑz ɡʊd dʒɹɑmə ɪn ðoʊz peɪdʒəz!

Mat hurried on, pushing his way out into the shaded noon, though he did catch a glimpse of Talmanes rolling his eyes. Burn the man! There was good drama in those pages!

θɹu ðə paɪn tʃɹiz i kəd si ðət ðə skaɪ wɑz klaʊɾi. əɡɛn. wən wɑz ðət ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɛnd?

Through the pine trees he could see that the sky was cloudy. Again. When was that going to end?

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz i wɔk θɹu kæmp, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹups ə soʊlʒɝz u ɔfɝɾ ɪm səluts əɹ kɔlz ʌv ɡɹiɾɪŋ tə "lɔɹd mæt." ðə bænd wɝ steɪɪŋ hɪɹ fəɹ ðə deɪ - kæmpt ɑn ə sɪkluɾɪd, wʊɾɪd hɪlsaɪɾ ə hæf-deɪ mɑɹtʃ fɹəm ðə taʊn - waɪl ðeɪ meɪd faɪnəl pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz fəɹ ði əsɔlt. ðə θɹi-niɾəl paɪnz hɪɹ wɝ tɔl, ən ðɛɹ lɪmz spɹɛd waɪd, ðə ʃeɪd kipɪŋ ʌndɝbɹʌʃ tə ə mɪnəməm. tɛns klʌstɝɾ ɪn ɡɹups ɝaʊn ðə paɪnz, ən ði ɛɹ wɑz kul ən ʃeɪɾɪd, smɛlɪŋ ə sæp ən loʊm.

Mat shook his head as he walked through camp, nodding to the groups of soldiers who offered him salutes or calls of greeting to "Lord Mat." The Band were staying here for the day - camped on a secluded, wooded hillside a half-day march from the town - while they made final preparations for the assault. The three-needle pines here were tall, and their limbs spread wide, the shade keeping underbrush to a minimum. Tents clustered in groups around the pines, and the air was cool and shaded, smelling of sap and loam.

hi wɛn əbaʊt ðə kæmp, tʃɛkɪŋ ɪndə ðə wɝkɪŋz ə hɪz mɛn ən siɪŋ ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz biɪŋ hændəld ɪfɪʃənli. ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz, ðə wʌnz ðət ði ɛlfɪn hæd ɡɪvən hɪm, hæd bɪɡʌn tə blɛn soʊ ivənli wɪð ɪz oʊn ðəɾ i kəd hɑɹdli tɛl wɪtʃ ɪnstɪŋks keɪm fɹəm əm ən wɪtʃ wɝ ɪz oʊn.
