He went about the camp, checking into the workings of his men and seeing that everything was being handled efficiently. Those old memories, the ones that the Eelfinn had given him, had begun to blend so evenly with his own that he could hardly tell which instincts came from them and which were his own.

ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə bi əmʌŋ ðə bæn əɡɛn; hi hædn ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ hid mɪs ðɛm. ɪt wəd bi naɪs tə ɹiunaɪt wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə mɛn, ðə tʃɹups lɛd baɪ ɛstin ən dɝəd. hoʊpfəli, ðeɪd hæɾ ən iziɝ taɪm ʌv ɪt ðən mæts fɔɹs hæd.

It was good to be among the Band again; he hadn't realized how much he'd missed them. It would be nice to reunite with the rest of the men, the troops led by Estean and Daerid. Hopefully, they'd had an easier time of it than Mat's force had.

ðə kævəlɹi bænɝz keɪm fɝst ɪn ɪz ɹaʊnz. ðeɪ wɝ sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kæmp -  hɔɹsmən ɔlweɪz kənsɪɾɝd ðɛmsɛlvz supɪɹiɝ tə fʊt. tədeɪ, əz ɔl tu ɔfən, ðə mɛn wɝ wɝiɾ əbaʊt fid fəɹ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. tə ə ɡʊd kævəlɹimən, hɪz hɔɹs ɔlweɪz keɪm fɝst. ðɛɹ tʃɹɪp fɹəm hɪndɝstæp hæd bɪn hɑɹɾ ɑn ði ænəməlz, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sɪns ðəɹ wɑzn mʌtʃ tə ɡɹeɪz ɑn. lɪɾəl wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ðɪs spɹɪŋ, ən ðə wɪntɝz livɪŋz wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒli spɑɹs. hɔɹsəz wəd ɹəfjuz pætʃəz ə θætʃ, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ɪt hæd ɡɔn bæd, laɪk ʌðɝ fud stɔɹz. ðeɪ dɪdn əv mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪn;

The cavalry banners came first in his rounds. They were separate from the rest of the camp -  horsemen always considered themselves superior to foot. Today, as all too often, the men were worried about feed for their horses. To a good cavalryman, his horse always came first. Their trip from Hinderstap had been hard on the animals, particularly since there wasn't much to graze on. Little was growing this spring, and the winter's leavings were strangely sparse. Horses would refuse patches of thatch, almost as if it had gone bad, like other food stores. They didn't have much grain;

ðeɪ hæd hoʊp tə lɪv ɔf ðə lænd, əz ðeɪ wɝ muvɪŋ tu kwɪkli fəɹ ɡɹeɪn wæɡənz.

they had hoped to live off the land, as they were moving too quickly for grain wagons.

wɛl, hid dʒʌst əv tə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ tə də əbaʊt ðæt. mæt əʃʊɹd ðə kævəlɹimən i wɑz wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðə pɹɑbləm, ən ðeɪ tʊk ɪm əɾ ɪz wɝd. lɔɹd mæt hædn lɛɾ əm daʊn jɛt. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə wʌnz i hæd lɛt daʊn wɝ ɹɑɾɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪvz. hi dɪnaɪɾ ə ɹɪkwɛs tə flaɪ ðə bænɝ.

Well, he'd just have to find something to do about that. Mat assured the cavalrymen he was working on the problem, and they took him at his word. Lord Mat hadn't let them down yet. Of course, the ones he had let down were rotting in their graves. He denied a request to fly the banner.

pɝhæps æftɝ ðə ɹeɪɾ ɑn tʃɹʌstɛɹ.

Perhaps after the raid on Trustair.

hi dɪdn əv ɛni tʃɹu fʊt wɪð ɪm ət ðə moʊmənt; ðeɪ wɝ ɔl wɪð ɛstin ən dɝəd.

He didn't have any true foot with him at the moment; they were all with Estean and Daerid.

tælmɑnz hæd waɪzli ʌndɝstʊd ðət ðeɪd nid moʊbɪləɾi, ən hæd bɹɔt ðə θɹi bænɝz ə hɔɹs ən nɪɹli fɔɹ θaʊzən maʊntəd kɹɔsboʊmən. mæt tʃɛkt ɑn ðə kɹɔsboʊmən nɛkst, pɔzɪŋ tə wɑtʃ ə kʌpəl ə skwɑdz dʒɹɪlɪŋ ɪn faɪɹɪŋ ɹæŋks ət ðə bæk ə ðə kæmp.

Talmanes had wisely understood that they'd need mobility, and had brought the three banners of horse and nearly four thousand mounted crossbowmen. Mat checked on the crossbowmen next, pausing to watch a couple of squads drilling in firing ranks at the back of the camp.

mæt stɑp bɪsaɪɾ ə tɔl paɪn, ɪts loʊəs bɹæntʃəz ə ɡʊd tu fiɾ əbʌv ɪz hɛd, linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə tʃɹʌŋk. ðə laɪn ə kɹɔsboʊmən wɝn pɹæktəsɪŋ ðɛɹ eɪm soʊ mʌtʃ əz ðɛɹ koʊɔɹɾəneɪʃən. jə dɪdn ɹɪli eɪm ɪn moʊs bæɾəlz, wɪtʃ wɑz waɪ ðə kɹɔsboʊz wɝk soʊ wɛl.

Mat stopped beside a tall pine, its lowest branches a good two feet above his head, leaning against the trunk. The line of crossbowmen weren't practicing their aim so much as their coordination. You didn't really aim in most battles, which was why the crossbows worked so well.

ðeɪ ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə tɛnθ ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ʌv ə lɔŋboʊ. ʃʊɹ, ðə læɾɝ kəd faɪɝ fæstɝ ən fɑɹðɝ, bʌɾ ɪf jə dɪdn əv ə laɪftaɪm tə spɛɹ pɹæktəsɪŋ, ðən ðiz kɹɔsboʊz wɝ ə faɪn sʌbstətut.

They required a tenth the training of a longbow. Sure, the latter could fire faster and farther, but if you didn't have a lifetime to spare practicing, then these crossbows were a fine substitute.

bɪsaɪdz, ðə kɹɔsboʊ ɹiloʊɾɪŋ pɹɑsɛs meɪɾ ɪɾ iziɝ tə tʃɹeɪn ðə ɹæŋks tə faɪɝ təɡɛðɝ. ðə skwɑdz kæptən stʊɾ ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪd, slæpɪŋ ə ɹɑɾ əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə tʃɹi wʌns ɛvɹi tu sɛkənz tə ɡɪv ə bit. itʃ kɹæk ə ðə wʊd wɑz ən ɔɹɾɝ. ɹeɪz kɹɔsboʊz tə ðə ʃoʊldɝ ɑn ðə fɝst.

Besides, the crossbow reloading process made it easier to train the ranks to fire together. The squad's captain stood on the far side, slapping a rod against the side of a tree once every two seconds to give a beat. Each crack of the wood was an order. Raise crossbows to the shoulder on the first.

faɪɝ ɑn ðə sɛkənd. loʊɝ ɑn ðə θɝd. kɹæŋk ɑn ðə fɔɹθ. ʌp tə ðə ʃoʊldɝ əɡɛn ɑn ðə fɪfθ. ðə mɛn wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɡʊd - faɪɹɪŋ ɪn koʊɔɹɾəneɪtɪd weɪvz meɪd fəɹ mɔɹ kənsɪstən kɪlɪŋ. itʃ fɔɹθ kɹæk lɛt lus ə weɪv ə boʊls ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz.

Fire on the second. Lower on the third. Crank on the fourth. Up to the shoulder again on the fifth. The men were getting good - firing in coordinated waves made for more consistent killing. Each fourth crack let loose a wave of bolts into the trees.

wɪl nid mɔɹ ə ðoʊz, mæt θɔt, noʊɾɪsɪŋ haʊ mɛni ʌv ðə boʊls splɪntɝd dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ʃɑts. jə weɪstəd mɔɹ æmjənɪʃən pɹæktəsɪŋ ðən jə dɪd faɪɾɪŋ, bʌɾ itʃ boʊl naʊ kəd bi wɝθ tu əɹ θɹi ɪn kɑmbæt. ðə mɛn wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɡʊɾ ɪndid. ɪf hid hæɾ ə fju bænɝz wɝθ ə ðiz wən hid fɔɾ ət blʌdwɑʃ fɔlz, pɝhæps næʃəf wʊɾə lɝn ɪz lɛsən ə lɑt sunɝ.

We'll need more of those, Mat thought, noticing how many of the bolts splintered during the training shots. You wasted more ammunition practicing than you did fighting, but each bolt now could be worth two or three in combat. The men were getting good indeed. If he'd had a few banners worth of these when he'd fought at Bloodwash Falls, perhaps Nashif would have learned his lesson a lot sooner.

ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪd bi mɔɹ jusfəl ɪf ðeɪ kəd faɪɝ fæstɝ. ðə kɹæŋkɪŋ wɑz ðə sloʊ pɔɪnt. nɑt ðə tɝn ə ðə kɹæŋk ɪtsɛlf, bʌt ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv loʊɝɪŋ ðə kɹɔsboʊ itʃ taɪm. ɪt kɑs fɔɹ sɛkənz dʒʌs tə muv ðə wɛpən əbaʊt. ðiz nu kɹæŋks ən bɑksəz ðət tælmɑnz hæd lɝn tə meɪk fɹəm ðət məkænɪk ɪn mʊɹændi spɛd θɪŋz ʌp ɡɹeɪtli. bʌt ðə məkænɪk hæd bɪn ɑn ɪz weɪ tə sɛl ðə kɹæŋks ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ən u nu hu ɛls hæd bɑɾ əm əlɔŋ ðə weɪ? bɪfɔɹ tu lɔŋ, ɛvɹiwʌn maɪɾ əv ðɛm. ən ædvæntɪdʒ wɑz niɡeɪɾɪd ɪf boʊθ jə ən jəɹ ɛnəmiz hæɾ ɪt.

Of course, they'd be more useful if they could fire faster. The cranking was the slow point. Not the turn of the crank itself, but the necessity of lowering the crossbow each time. It cost four seconds just to move the weapon about. These new cranks and boxes that Talmanes had learned to make from that mechanic in Murandy sped things up greatly. But the mechanic had been on his way to sell the cranks in Caemlyn, and who knew who else had bought them along the way? Before too long, everyone might have them. An advantage was negated if both you and your enemies had it.

ðoʊz bɑksəz hæd ɡɪvən ə lɑt tə mæts səksɛs ɪn ɔltɑɹə əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn. hi wɑz loʊθ tə sɝɛndɝ ði ædvæntɪdʒ. kəɾ i faɪn ə weɪ tə meɪk ðə baʊz faɪɝ ivən fæstɝ?

Those boxes had given a lot to Mat's success in Altara against the Seanchan. He was loath to surrender the advantage. Could he find a way to make the bows fire even faster?

θɔtfəl, hi tʃɛkt ɑn ə fju mɔɹ θɪŋz ɪn ðə kæmp - ði ɔltɑɹənz ðeɪd ɹɪkɹuɾɪd ɪndə ðə bænd wɝ sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn wɛl, ən ʌðɝ ðən fid fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz ən pɝhæps kɹɔsboʊ boʊls, səplaɪz lʊkt ɡʊd. sæɾəsfaɪd, hi wɛn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɑlʌdʒɹə.

Thoughtful, he checked on a few more things in the camp - the Altarans they'd recruited into the Band were settling in well, and other than feed for the horses and perhaps crossbow bolts, supplies looked good. Satisfied, he went looking for Aludra.

ʃi hæɾ ɪstæblɪʃt hɝsɛlf nɪɹ ðə bæk ə ðə kæmp, əlɔŋsaɪɾ ə lɪɾəl klft ɪn ðə ɹɑki hɪlsaɪd.

She had established herself near the back of the camp, alongside a little cleft in the rocky hillside.

ðoʊ ðɪs spɑt wɑz mʌtʃ smɔlɝ ðən ðə ɡleɪɾ ə tʃɹiz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðɛɹ ətɛndəns juzd, ɪt wɑz noʊɾɪsəbli mɔɹ sɪkluɾɪd. mæt hæd tə wiv ɝaʊn θɹi sɛpɹət klɔθ ʃits hæŋɪŋ bɪtwin tʃɹiz - pleɪs kɛɹfəli tə blɑk ɛni vju ɪndə ɑlʌdʒɹəz wɝkspeɪs - bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt hɝ. ən i hæd tə stɑp wən beɪl doʊmən hɛld aʊɾ ə hænd, hoʊldɪŋ mæt bæk əntɪl ɑlʌdʒɹə ɡeɪv liv fəɹ ɪm tə ɛntɝ.

Though this spot was much smaller than the glade of trees the Aes Sedai and their attendants used, it was noticeably more secluded. Mat had to weave around three separate cloth sheets hanging between trees - placed carefully to block any view into Aludra's workspace - before he reached her. And he had to stop when Bayle Domon held out a hand, holding Mat back until Aludra gave leave for him to enter.

ðə slɛndɝ, dɑɹk-hɛɹɾ ɪluməneɪɾɝ sæɾ ɑn ə stʌmp ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə hɝ lɪɾəl kæmp, paʊɾɝz, ɹoʊlz ə peɪpɝ, ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹd fəɹ noʊts ən tulz nitli ɝeɪnʒd ɑn stʃɹɪps ə klɔθ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɔɹ əɹ bɹeɪdz, ən əɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ fɛl lus ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ðət meɪɾ əɹ lʊk ɑd tə mæt. stɪl pɹɪɾi, ðoʊ.

The slender, dark-haired Illuminator sat on a stump in the center of her little camp, powders, rolls of paper, a writing board for notes and tools neatly arranged on strips of cloth on the ground around her. She no longer wore her braids, and her long hair fell loose around her shoulders. That made her look odd to Mat. Still pretty, though.

bɝn ɪt, mæt. jəɹ mɛɹid naʊ, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. ɑlʌdʒɹə wɑz pɹɪɾi, ðoʊ.

Burn it, Mat. You're married now, he told himself. Aludra was pretty, though.

ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, hoʊldɪŋ ə naɪtfloʊɝ ʃɛl əpɹaɪt fəɹ ɑlʌdʒɹə tə wɝk ɑn. ɑlʌdʒɹəz fʊl- lɪp feɪs fɹaʊn ɪn kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən əz ʃi tæp laɪtli ɑn ðə ʃɛl. ɛdʒiənɪnz dɑɹk hɛɹ wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ aʊt, meɪkɪŋ əɹ lʊk lɛs ən lɛs laɪk wʌn ə ðə sintʃæn noʊbɪləɾi. mæt stɪl hæd tʃɹʌbəl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd wʌt tə kɔl ðə wʊmən. ʃi wɑntəd tə bi noʊn əz laɪlwɪn, ən səmtaɪmz i θɔɾ ə hɝ laɪk ðæt. ɪt wɑz fulɪʃ tə ɡoʊ əbaʊt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ jəɹ neɪm dʒʌs kəz sʌmwʌn sɛd jə hæd tə, bʌɾ i dɪdn ɹɪli bleɪm əɹ fəɹ nɑt wɑntɪŋ tə ɹaɪl tuɑn. ʃi wɑz ə blʌɾi stʌbɝn wʌn, tuɑn wɑz. hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɡlænsɪŋ tə ðə saʊθ əɡɛn, bʌt kɑt hɪmsɛlf. blʌɾ ən æʃəz! ʃid bi dʒʌs faɪn.

Egeanin was there, holding a nightflower shell upright for Aludra to work on. Aludra's full- lipped face frowned in concentration as she tapped lightly on the shell. Egeanin's dark hair was growing out, making her look less and less like one of the Seanchan nobility. Mat still had trouble trying to decide what to call the woman. She wanted to be known as Leilwin, and sometimes he thought of her like that. It was foolish to go about changing your name just because someone said you had to, but he didn't really blame her for not wanting to rile Tuon. She was a bloody stubborn one, Tuon was. He found himself glancing to the south again, but caught himself. Blood and ashes! She'd be just fine.

ɛniweɪ, tuɑn wɑz ɡɔn naʊ. soʊ waɪ dɪɾ ɛdʒiənɪn kəntɪnju ðə ʃɝeɪɾ ə kɔlɪŋ hɝsɛlf laɪlwɪn? mæt hæɾ æktʃəli  kɔld əɹ baɪ hɝ oʊl neɪm wʌns əɹ twaɪs æftɝ tuɑnz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, bʌt hæd ɹəsivd ə kɝt ɹɛpɹəmænd. wɪmən! ðeɪ meɪd noʊ sɛns, ən sintʃæn wɪmən list ʌv ɔl.

Anyway, Tuon was gone now. So why did Egeanin continue the charade of calling herself Leilwin? Mat had actually called her by her old name once or twice after Tuon's departure, but had received a curt reprimand. Women! They made no sense, and Seanchan women least of all.

mæt ɡlænst ət beɪl doʊmən. ðə mʌskjəlɝ, bɪɹɾəd ɪliɑnɝ lin əɡɛnst ə tʃɹi nɪɹ ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ɑlʌdʒɹəz kæmp, tu flæpɪŋ waɪt ʃits ə klɔθ ɪkstɛndɪŋ ɪn iðɝ dɝɛkʃən nɪɹ hɪm.

Mat glanced at Bayle Domon. The muscular, bearded Illianer leaned against a tree near the entrance to Aludra's camp, two flapping white sheets of cloth extending in either direction near him.

hi stɪl hɛld aʊɾ ə wɔɹnɪŋ hænd. əz ɪf ðɪs ɪntaɪɝ kæmp wɝn mæts ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs!

He still held out a warning hand. As if this entire camp weren't Mat's in the first place!

mæt dɪdn pʊʃ ɪz weɪ pæst, ðoʊ. hi kʊdn əfɔɹd tə əfɛn ɑlʌdʒɹə. ʃi wɑz fleɪmɪŋ kloʊz tə biɪŋ dʌn wɪð ðoʊz dʒɹæɡən dɪzaɪnz ə hɝz, ən i mɛn tə hæv ðoʊz. bʌt laɪt, ɪf ɪt dɪdn smɑɹt tə hæv tə pæs ə tʃɛkpɔɪn ɪn ɪz oʊn kæmp!

Mat didn't push his way past, though. He couldn't afford to offend Aludra. She was flaming close to being done with those dragon designs of hers, and he meant to have those. But Light, if it didn't smart to have to pass a checkpoint in his own camp!

ɑlʌdʒɹə lʊkt ʌp fɹəm əɹ wɝk, tʌkɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪ lɑk ə hɛɹ bɪhaɪn əɹ ɪɹ. ʃi noʊɾəd mæt, ðən lʊk bæk tə hɝ naɪtfloʊɝ ən bɪɡæn tæpɪŋ wɪð ðə hæmɝ əɡɛn. blʌɾi æʃəz! siɪŋ ðət ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm waɪ hi vɪzəɾəd ɑlʌdʒɹə soʊ ɪnfɹikwənli. ðə tʃɛkpɔɪnt wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf, bʌt dɪd ðə wʊmən əv tə paʊn ɑn sʌmθɪŋ ɪksploʊsɪv wɪð ə hæmɝ? hæd ʃi noʊ sɛns əɾ ɔl? ði ɪntaɪɝ lɑɾ ʌv ɪluməneɪɾɝz wɝ ðət weɪ, ðoʊ. ʃɔɹɾ ə fju foʊlz ʌv ə fʊl hɝd, əz mæts fɑðɝ maɪt seɪ.

Aludra looked up from her work, tucking a stray lock of hair behind her ear. She noted Mat, then looked back to her nightflower and began tapping with the hammer again. Bloody ashes! Seeing that reminded him why he visited Aludra so infrequently. The checkpoint was bad enough, but did the woman have to pound on something explosive with a hammer? Had she no sense at all? The entire lot of Illuminators were that way, though. Short a few foals of a full herd, as Mat's father might say.

"hi meɪ ɛntɝ," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd. "θæŋk ju, mæstɝ doʊmən."

"He may enter," Aludra said. "Thank you, Master Domon."

"ɪt də bi ə plɛʒɝ, mɪstʃɹəs ɑlʌdʒɹə," beɪl sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ɪz hæn ən nɑɾɪŋ eɪmiəbli tə mæt. mæt stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪz koʊɾ ən wɔk fɔɹwɝd, ɪntɛn ɑn æskɪŋ əbaʊt kɹɔsboʊz. sʌmθɪŋ ɪmiɾiətli kɑɾ ɪz aɪ, haʊɛvɝ. spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪhaɪn ɑlʌdʒɹə wɝ ə sɪɹiz ə nit peɪdʒəz wɪð dɪteɪl dʒɹɔɪŋz, əlɔŋ wɪð ə lɪst ə noʊteɪʃənz wɪð nʌmbɝz bɪsaɪd ðɛm.

"It do be a pleasure, Mistress Aludra," Bayle said, lowering his hand and nodding amiably to Mat. Mat straightened his coat and walked forward, intent on asking about crossbows. Something immediately caught his eye, however. Spread out on the ground behind Aludra were a series of neat pages with detailed drawings, along with a list of notations with numbers beside them.

"ɑɹ ðiz ðə plænz fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡənz?" mæt æskt iɡɝli. hi nɛl daʊn ɑn wʌn ni tə ɪnspɛk ðə ʃits, wɪθaʊt tʌtʃɪŋ ðɛm. ɑlʌdʒɹə kəd bi pɝtɪkjəlɝ əbaʊt ðət kaɪndə θɪŋ.

"Are these the plans for the dragons?" Mat asked eagerly. He knelt down on one knee to inspect the sheets, without touching them. Aludra could be particular about that kind of thing.

"jɛs." ʃi wɑz stɪl tæpɪŋ wɪð əɹ hæmɝ. ʃi aɪd hɪm, lʊkɪŋ dʒʌs feɪnli ənkʌmftəɹbəl.

"Yes." She was still tapping with her hammer. She eyed him, looking just faintly uncomfortable.

kəz ə tuɑn, hi səspɛktəd.

Because of Tuon, he suspected.

"æn ðiz fɪɡjɝz?" mæt tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ði ɔkwɝdnəs.

"And these figures?" Mat tried to ignore the awkwardness.

"səplaɪ ɹɪkwaɪɹməns," ʃi sɛd. ʃi pʊt daʊn əɹ hæmɝ ən ɪnspɛktɪd ðə səlɪnʒɹɪkəl naɪtfloʊɝ fɹəm ɔl saɪdz. ʃi nɑɾəd tə laɪlwɪn.

"Supply requirements," she said. She put down her hammer and inspected the cylindrical nightflower from all sides. She nodded to Leilwin.

blʌɾi æʃəz, bʌt ðə fɪɡjɝz wɝ lɑɹdʒ! ə maʊntən ə tʃɑɹkoʊl, sʌlfɝ ən . . . bæt ɡwɑnoʊ? ðə noʊts kleɪm ðəɹ wɑz ə sɪɾi spɛʃəlaɪzɪŋ ɪn pɹədusɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪn ðə nɔɹðɝn ɹitʃəz ə ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. wʌt sɪɾi spɛʃəlaɪzd ɪn ɡæðɝɪŋ bæt ɡwɑnoʊ, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz? ðəɹ wɝ ɹɪkwaɪɹməns fəɹ kɑpɝ ən tɪn əz wɛl, ðoʊ fəɹ səm ɹizən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ nʌmbɝz bɪsaɪd ðoʊz.

Bloody ashes, but the figures were large! A mountain of charcoal, sulphur and . . . bat guano? The notes claimed there was a city specializing in producing it over in the northern reaches of the Mountains of Mist. What city specialized in gathering bat guano, of all things? There were requirements for copper and tin as well, though for some reason there were no numbers beside those.

dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl stɑɹ noʊteɪʃən.

Just a little star notation.

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. haʊ wəd ðə kɑmən pipəl ɹiækt ɪf ðeɪ nu ðət ðə mədʒɛstɪk naɪtfloʊɝz wɝ dʒʌst ə peɪpɝ, paʊɾɝ ən - ʌv ɔl θɪŋz - bæt dʌŋ? noʊ wʌndɝ ɪluməneɪɾɝz wɝ soʊ sikɹəɾɪv wɪð ðɛɹ kɹæft. ɪt wɑzn dʒʌst əbaʊt pɹɪvɛntɪŋ kɑmpətɪʃən. ðə mɔɹ jə nu əbaʊt ðə pɹɑsɛs, ðə lɛs wʌnʒɹəs ən mɔɹ ɔɹɾənɛɹi ɪt bɪkeɪm.

Mat shook his head. How would the common people react if they knew that the majestic nightflowers were just a paper, powder and - of all things - bat dung? No wonder Illuminators were so secretive with their craft. It wasn't just about preventing competition. The more you knew about the process, the less wondrous and more ordinary it became.

"ðɪs ɪz ə lɑɾ ə mətɪɹiəl," mæt sɛd.

"This is a lot of material," Mat said.

"ə mɪɹəkəl, ðəɾ ɪz wʌt jə æsk mi fɔɹ, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd, hændɪŋ əɹ naɪtfloʊɝ tə laɪlwɪn ən pɪkɪŋ ʌp əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹd. ʃi meɪd səm noʊteɪʃənz ɑn ðə ʃit stʃɹæp tə ðə fɹʌnt. "ðæt mɪɹəkəl, aɪ hæv bɹoʊkən daʊn ɪndə ə lɪst ʌv ɪnɡɹiɾiənts. ə fit wɪtʃ ɪz ɪn ɪtsɛlf mɝækjələs, jɛs? də nɑt kəmpleɪn ə ðə hit wən sʌmwʌn ɔfɝz jə ðə sʌn ɪn ðə pɑm ə hɝ hænz."

"A miracle, that is what you asked me for, Matrim Cauthon," she replied, handing her nightflower to Leilwin and picking up her writing board. She made some notations on the sheet strapped to the front. "That miracle, I have broken down into a list of ingredients. A feat which is in itself miraculous, yes? Do not complain of the heat when someone offers you the sun in the palm of her hands."

"dʌzn sim soʊ mænɪdʒəbəl tə mi," mæt mʌɾɝd, moʊsli tə hɪmsɛlf. "ɪz ðɪs fɪɡjɝ ðə kɑsts?"

"Doesn't seem so manageable to me," Mat muttered, mostly to himself. "Is this figure the costs?"

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ə skɹaɪb," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd. "ðoʊz ɑɹ ɛstəməts oʊnli. ðə kælkjəleɪʃənz, aɪ hæv teɪkən əm əz fɑɹ əz aɪ kən ɡoʊ, bʌt ðə ɹɛst wɪl əv tə bi fɪɡjɝd baɪ ðoʊz mɔɹ pɹɑfɪʃənt. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, hi kən əfɔɹd sətʃ kɑsts." laɪlwɪn wɑtʃt mæt wɪð ə kjʊɹiəs ɪkspɹɛʃən. θɪŋz hæd tʃeɪnʒd wɪð hɝ, tu, kəz ə tuɑn. bʌt nɑɾ ɪn ðə weɪ hiɾ ɪkspɛktəd.

"I am not a scribe," Aludra said. "Those are estimates only. The calculations, I have taken them as far as I can go, but the rest will have to be figured by those more proficient. The Dragon Reborn, he can afford such costs." Leilwin watched Mat with a curious expression. Things had changed with her, too, because of Tuon. But not in the way he'd expected.

mɛnʃən ə ɹænd bɹɔt ðə kʌlɝz swɝlɪŋ ɪndə mæts vɪʒən, ən i səpɹɛst ə saɪ əz i ʃʊk əm əweɪ. meɪbi ɹænd kəd mænədʒ kɑsts laɪk ðiz, bʌt mæt sɝɾənli kʊdnt. waɪ, hiɾ əv tə daɪs wɪð ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ hɝsɛlf tə faɪn ðɪs kaɪndə kɔɪn!

Mention of Rand brought the colors swirling into Mat's vision, and he suppressed a sigh as he shook them away. Maybe Rand could manage costs like these, but Mat certainly couldn't. Why, he'd have to dice with the queen of Andor herself to find this kind of coin!

bʌt ðət wɑz ɹændz pɹɑbləm. bɝn hɪm, hid bɛɾɝ əpɹiʃieɪt wʌt mæt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu fəɹ hɪm. "ðɪs dʌzn ɪnkluɾ ə mænpaʊɝ ɛstəmət," mæt noʊɾəst, skænɪŋ ðə ʃits əɡɛn. "haʊ mɛni bɛlfndɝz ɑɹ jə gɑnə nid fəɹ ðɪs pɹɑdʒɛkt?"

But that was Rand's problem. Burn him, he'd better appreciate what Mat was going through for him. "This doesn't include a manpower estimate," Mat noticed, scanning the sheets again. "How many bellfounders are you going to need for this project?"

"ɛvɹi wʌn jə kən ɡɛt," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd kɝtli. "ɪz ðət nɑt wʌt jə pɹɑməs mi? ɛvɹi bɛlfndɝ fɹəm ændɝ tə tɛɹ."

"Every one you can get," Aludra said curtly. "Is that not what you promised me? Every bellfounder from Andor to Tear."

"aɪ səpoʊz," mæt sɛd. hi hædn æktʃəli  ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə teɪk ɪm lɪɾɝəli ɑn ðæt. "wʌɾ əbaʊt kɑpɝ ən tɪn? jə doʊn əv ən ɛstəməɾ ə ðoʊz."

"I suppose," Mat said. He hadn't actually expected her to take him literally on that. "What about copper and tin? You don't have an estimate of those."

"aɪ niɾ ɔl ʌv ɪt."

"I need all of it."

"ɔl ʌv. . . . wʌt dʒju min, ɔl ʌv ɪt?"

"All of. . . . What do you mean, all of it?"

"ɔl ʌv ɪt," ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd, əz sɪmpli ən kɑmli əz ɪf ʃi wɝ æskɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ klaʊdbɛɹi dʒæm fəɹ əɹ pɔɹədʒ. "ɛvɹi skɹæp ə kɑpɝ ən tɪn jə kən skɹaʊnʒ ʌp ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld." ʃi pɔzd. "pɝhæps ðət dʌz sim tu æmbɪʃəs."

"All of it," she repeated, as simply and calmly as if she were asking for more cloudberry jam for her porridge. "Every scrap of copper and tin you can scrounge up this side of the Spine of the World." She paused. "Perhaps that does seem too ambitious."

"blʌɾi ɹaɪɾ ɪts æmbɪʃəs," mæt mʌɾɝd.

"Bloody right it's ambitious," Mat muttered.

"jɛs," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd. "lɛɾ əs əsum ðə dʒɹæɡən əz kəntʃɹoʊl ə keɪɛmlɪn, kɛɹhin, ɪljən ən tiɹ.

"Yes," Aludra said. "Let us assume the Dragon has control of Caemlyn, Cairhien, Illian and Tear.

ɪf i wɝ tə pɹəvaɪd mi wɪð æksɛs tə itʃ ən ɛvɹi maɪn ən mɛɾəl stɔɹ ə kɑpɝ ən tɪn ɪn ðoʊz fɔɹ sɪɾiz, aɪ səpoʊz ɪt wəd bi səfɪʃənt."

If he were to provide me with access to each and every mine and metal store of copper and tin in those four cities, I suppose it would be sufficient."

"ɛvɹi mɛɾəl stɔɹ," mæt sɛd flætli.

"Every metal store," Mat said flatly.

"jɛs."

"Yes."

"ɪn fɔɹ ə ðə wɝlz lɑɹdʒəst sɪɾiz."

"In four of the world's largest cities."

"jɛs."

"Yes."

"æn jə 'səpoʊz' ðət wəd bi səfɪʃənt."

"And you 'suppose' that would be sufficient."

"aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ sɛd, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən."

"I believe that is what I said, Matrim Cauthon."

"ɡɹeɪt. əl si wʌɾ aɪ kən də əbaʊt ðæt. wəd jə laɪk ðə blʌɾi dɑɹk wʌn tə kʌm pɑlɪʃ jəɹ ʃuz waɪl jəɹ əɾ ɪt? meɪbi wi kəd dɪɡ ʌp ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ən ɡɛɾ ɪm tə də ə dæns fəɹ ju."

"Great. I'll see what I can do about that. Would you like the bloody Dark One to come polish your shoes while you're at it? Maybe we could dig up Artur Hawkwing and get him to do a dance for you."

laɪlwɪn ɡeɪv mæt ə ɡlɛɹ ət ðə mɛnʃən ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ɑlʌdʒɹə fɪnɪʃt əɹ ənəteɪʃənz, ðən tɝn tə ɹəɡɑɹd mæt. ʃi spoʊk flætli, dʒʌs veɪɡli hɑstəl. "maɪ dʒɹæɡənz, ðəl bi ə ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ fəɹ ə mæn ʌv wɔɹ. jə kleɪm wʌɾ aɪ hæv ɡɪvən jə ɪz ɪkstʃɹævəɡənt. ɪts oʊnli niɾəd." ʃi aɪd hɪm. "aɪ wɪl nɑt laɪ ən seɪ aɪ dɪdn ɪkspɛk ðɪs dɪsmɪsɪvnəs fɹəm ju, mæstɝ kɔθən. pɛsəmɪzəm, ʃiz ə fɑn fɹɛn ə jʊɹz, jɛs?"

Leilwin gave Mat a glare at the mention of Artur Hawkwing. After a moment, Aludra finished her annotations, then turned to regard Mat. She spoke flatly, just vaguely hostile. "My dragons, they will be a great power for a man of war. You claim what I have given you is extravagant. It is only needed." She eyed him. "I will not lie and say I didn't expect this dismissiveness from you, Master Cauthon. Pessimism, she is a fond friend of yours, yes?"

"ðæts ənkɔl fɔɹ," mæt ɡɹʌmbəld, ɡlænsɪŋ bæk daʊn ət ðə dʒɹɔɪŋz. "aɪ bɛɹli noʊ hɝ.

"That's uncalled for," Mat grumbled, glancing back down at the drawings. "I barely know her.

mɪɹ əkweɪntənsɪz, ət bɛst. juv ɡɑt maɪ oʊθ ɑn ɪt."

Mere acquaintances, at best. You've got my oath on it."

ðəɾ ɝn ə snɔɹt fɹəm beɪl. wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz wʌn ʌv əmjuzmən əɹ dɝɪʒən wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə tɛl wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk tə dʒʌdʒ ɪz feɪs. mæt dɪdnt ɡlæns ət hɪm. ɑlʌdʒɹə wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm. ðɛɹ aɪz mɛt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən mæt ɹilaɪz hid pɹɑbli bɪn tu kɝt wɪð hɝ. meɪbi hi wɑz ənkʌmftəɹbəl ɝaʊn hɝ. ə lɪɾəl. ðeɪd bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊs bɪfɔɹ tuɑn. ən wɑz ðət peɪn, hɪɾən ɪn ɑlʌdʒɹəz aɪz?

That earned a snort from Bayle. Whether it was one of amusement or derision was impossible to tell without looking back to judge his face. Mat didn't glance at him. Aludra was staring at him. Their eyes met for a moment, and Mat realized he'd probably been too curt with her. Maybe he was uncomfortable around her. A little. They'd been getting close before Tuon. And was that pain, hidden in Aludra's eyes?

"aɪm sɑɹi, ɑlʌdʒɹə," hi sɛd. "aɪ ʃʊdn əv tɔk laɪk ðæt."

"I'm sorry, Aludra," he said. "I shouldn't have talked like that."

ʃi ʃɹʌɡd.

She shrugged.

hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "lʊk, aɪ noʊ ðət . . . wɛl, ɪts ɑd haʊ tuɑn - "

He took a deep breath. "Look, I know that . . . well, it's odd how Tuon - "

ʃi weɪvd ə hænd, kʌɾɪŋ ɪm ɔf. "ɪɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ. aɪ hæv maɪ dʒɹæɡənz. juv bɹɔt mi ðə tʃæns tə kɹieɪt ðɛm. ʌðɝ mæɾɝz ɑɹ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə kənsɝn. aɪ wɪʃ jə hæpinəs."

She waved a hand, cutting him off. "It is nothing. I have my dragons. You have brought me the chance to create them. Other matters are no longer of concern. I wish you happiness."

"wɛl," hi sɛd. hi ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn, ðən saɪd. bɛs tə dʒʌs lɛɾ ɪt pæs. "ɛniweɪ, aɪ hoʊp aɪ kən ɡɛt ðɪs dʌn. jə æsk fəɹ ə lɑɾ ə ɹisɔɹsɪz."

"Well," he said. He rubbed his chin, then sighed. Best to just let it pass. "Anyway, I hope I can get this done. You ask for a lot of resources."

"ðiz bɛlfndɝz ən mətɪɹiəlz," ʃi sɛd, "ðeɪ ɑɹ wʌɾ aɪ nid. noʊ mɔɹ ən noʊ lɛs. aɪ hæv dʌn wʌɾ aɪ kən hɪɹ, wɪθaʊt ɹisɔɹsɪz. əl stɪl nid tə spɛnd wiks tɛstɪŋ - wɪl nid tə meɪk ə sɪŋɡəl dʒɹæɡən fɝst, tə tʃɛk. soʊ juv səm taɪm tə ɡæðɝ ɔl ə ðɪs. bʌɾ ɪɾəl teɪk mʌtʃ taɪm, ən jɛt jə ɹəfjuz tə tɛl mi wən ðə dʒɹæɡənz wɪl bi niɾəd."

"These bellfounders and materials," she said, "they are what I need. No more and no less. I have done what I can here, without resources. I will still need to spend weeks testing - we will need to make a single dragon first, to check. So you have some time to gather all of this. But it will take much time, and yet you refuse to tell me when the dragons will be needed."

"kæn tɛl jə θɪŋz aɪ doʊnt noʊ maɪsɛlf, ɑlʌdʒɹə," mæt sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd. hi fɛlt ə stʃɹeɪnʒ tʌɡɪŋ, əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd hʊkt ə fɪʃɝmænz laɪn əbaʊɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪdz ən wɑz sɔfli - bʌɾ ɪnsɪstənli - pʊlɪŋ ɑn ɪt. ɹænd, ɪz ðət ju, bɝn ju? kʌlɝz swɝld. "sun, ɑlʌdʒɹə," hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf seɪɪŋ. "taɪm ɪz ʃɔɹt. soʊ ʃɔɹt."

"Can't tell you things I don't know myself, Aludra," Mat said, glancing northward. He felt a strange tugging, as if someone had hooked a fisherman's line about his insides and was softly - but insistently - pulling on it. Rand, is that you, burn you? Colors swirled. "Soon, Aludra," he found himself saying. "Time is short. So short."

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, əz ɪf sɛnsɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "wɛl," ʃi sɛd. "ɪf ðət bi ðə keɪs, ðən maɪ ɹɪkwɛsts ɑɹ nɑt soʊ ɪkstʃɹævəɡənt, jɛs? ɪf ðə wɝld ɡoʊz tə wɔɹ, ðə fɔɹdʒɪz wɪl sun bi niɾəd fəɹ æɹoʊhɛdz ən hɔɹsʃuz. bɛɾɝ tə pʊɾ əm tə wɝk naʊ ɑn maɪ dʒɹæɡənz. lemi əʃʊɹ ju, itʃ wʌn wi fɪnɪʃ wɪl bi wɝθ ə θaʊzən sɔɹdz ɪn bæɾəl."

She hesitated, as if sensing something in his voice. "Well," she said. "If that be the case, then my requests are not so extravagant, yes? If the world goes to war, the forges will soon be needed for arrowheads and horseshoes. Better to put them to work now on my dragons. Let me assure you, each one we finish will be worth a thousand swords in battle."

mæt saɪd, stʊɾ ʌp ən tɪpt ɪz hæt tə hɝ. "ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn," hi sɛd. "fɛɹ ɪnʌf. əsumɪŋ ɹænd dʌzn blʌɾi bɝn mi tə ə kɹɪsp ðə moʊmən aɪ sədʒɛs ðɪs, əl si wʌɾ aɪ kən du."

Mat sighed, stood up and tipped his hat to her. "All right, then," he said. "Fair enough. Assuming Rand doesn't bloody burn me to a crisp the moment I suggest this, I'll see what I can do."

"ju wəd bi waɪz tə ʃoʊ mɪstʃɹəs ɑlʌdʒɹə ɹɪspɛkt," laɪlwɪn sɛd, aɪɪŋ mæt, spikɪŋ wɪð ðət sloʊ sintʃæn dʒɹɔl. "ɹæðɝ ðən biɪŋ soʊ flɪpən təwɔɹd hɝ."

"You would be wise to show Mistress Aludra respect," Leilwin said, eyeing Mat, speaking with that slow Seanchan drawl. "Rather than being so flippant toward her."

"ðæt wɑz sənsɪɹ!" mæt sɛd. "ðæt læs pɑɹt wɑz, ət list. bɝn mi, wʊmən. kæn jə tɛl wən ə mænz biɪŋ sənsɪɹ?"

"That was sincere!" Mat said. "That last part was, at least. Burn me, woman. Can't you tell when a man's being sincere?"

ʃi aɪd hɪm, əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪɾ ɪf ðət vɛɹi pɹənaʊnsmənt wɝ səm kaɪndə mɑkɝi. mæt ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz. wɪmən!

She eyed him, as if trying to decide if that very pronouncement were some kind of mockery. Mat rolled his eyes. Women!

"mɪstʃɹəs ɑlʌdʒɹə ɪz bɹɪljənt," laɪlwɪn sɛd stɝnli. "ju doʊn ʌndɝstæn ðə ɡɪft ʃiz ɡɪvɪŋ jə ɪn ðiz plænz. waɪ, ɪf ði ɛmpaɪɝ hæd ðiz wɛpənz. . . ."

"Mistress Aludra is brilliant," Leilwin said sternly. "You don't understand the gift she is giving you in these plans. Why, if the Empire had these weapons. . . ."

"wɛl, si ðət jə doʊnt ɡɪv əm tə ɪt, laɪlwɪn," mæt sɛd. "aɪ doʊnt wɑnə weɪk ʌp wʌn mɔɹnɪŋ ən faɪn ðət juv ɹʌn ɔf wɪð ðiz plænz ɪn ən ətɛmpt ət ɹitʃɹivɪŋ jəɹ taɪɾəl!"

"Well, see that you don't give them to it, Leilwin," Mat said. "I don't want to wake up one morning and find that you've run off with these plans in an attempt at retrieving your title!"

ʃi lʊkt ɪnsʌltɪd ðət hid sədʒɛst sətʃ ə θɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪt sim laɪk ðə lɑdʒɪkəl θɪŋ tə du.

She looked insulted that he'd suggest such a thing, though it seemed like the logical thing to do.

sintʃæn hæɾ ən ɑd sɛns ʌv ɑnɝ - tuɑn hædn tʃɹaɪd wʌns tə fli fɹəm hɪm, ðoʊ ʃid hæɾ æmpəl ɑpɝtunəɾi.

Seanchan had an odd sense of honor - Tuon hadn't tried once to flee from him, though she'd had ample opportunity.

ʌv kɔɹs, tuɑn hæd səspɛktəd fɹəm nɪɹ ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ðət ʃid mɛɹi hɪm. ʃid hæd ðət deɪmeɪnz fɔɹtɛlɪŋ. bɝn hɪm, hi wʊdn lʊk saʊθwɝɾ əɡɛn. hi wʊdnt!

Of course, Tuon had suspected from near the beginning that she'd marry him. She'd had that damane's Foretelling. Burn him, he wouldn't look southward again. He wouldn't!

"maɪ ʃɪp ɪz biɪŋ dʒɹɪvən baɪ dɪfɹənt wɪnz naʊ, mæstɝ kɔθən," laɪlwɪn sɛd sɪmpli, tɝnɪŋ fɹəm ɪm ən ɡlænsɪŋ ət beɪl.

"My ship is being driven by different winds now, Master Cauthon," Leilwin said simply, turning from him and glancing at Bayle.

"bʌt jə wʊdn hɛlp əs faɪt ðə sintʃæn," mæt pɹətɛstəd. "ɪt simz ðət jud - "

"But you wouldn't help us fight the Seanchan," Mat protested. "It seems that you'd - "

"ju də bi swɪmɪŋ ɪn dip wɔɾɝ ɹaɪt naʊ, læd," beɪl ɪntɝdʒɛktɪɾ ɪn ə sɑf vɔɪs. "aɪ, dip wɔɾɝ, fɪld wɪð laɪənfɪʃ. ɪt meɪ bi taɪm tə stɑp splæʃɪŋ soʊ laʊdli."

"You do be swimming in deep water right now, lad," Bayle interjected in a soft voice. "Aye, deep water, filled with lionfish. It may be time to stop splashing so loudly."

mæt kloʊzd ɪz maʊð. "ɔl ɹaɪt ðɛn," hi sɛd. ʃʊdn ðə tu ʌv əm bi tʃɹiɾɪŋ ɪm wɪð mɔɹ ɹɪspɛkt? wɑzn i səm kaɪndə haɪ sintʃæn pɹɪns əɹ sʌmθɪŋ? hi ʃʊɾə noʊn ðət wʊdn hɛlp ɪm wɪð laɪlwɪn əɹ ðə bɪɹɾəd seɪlɝ.

Mat closed his mouth. "All right then," he said. Shouldn't the two of them be treating him with more respect? Wasn't he some kind of high Seanchan prince or something? He should have known that wouldn't help him with Leilwin or the bearded sailor.

ɛniweɪ, hi hæd bɪn sənsɪɹ. ɑlʌdʒɹəz wɝdz meɪd sɛns, kɹeɪzi ðoʊ ðeɪ saʊndəɾ ət fɝst.

Anyway, he had been sincere. Aludra's words made sense, crazy though they sounded at first.

ðeɪ wəd nid tə dɛɾəkeɪt ə lɑɾ ə faʊnʒɹiz tə ðə wɝk. ðə wiks ɪt wɑz gɑnə teɪk ɪm tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn simd ivən mɔɹ ɡɔlɪŋ naʊ. ðoʊz wiks spɛn ɑn ðə ɹoʊd ʃəd bi spɛn bɪldɪŋ dʒɹæɡənz! ə waɪz mæn lɝn ðət ðəɹ wɑz noʊ jus fɹɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ lɔŋ mɑɹtʃɪz - bʌt mæt fɛl fɑɹ fɹəm waɪz leɪtli.

They would need to dedicate a lot of foundries to the work. The weeks it was going to take him to reach Caemlyn seemed even more galling now. Those weeks spent on the road should be spent building dragons! A wise man learned that there was no use fretting over long marches - but Mat felt far from wise lately.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛɾ əɡɛn. hi lʊk bæk əɾ ɑlʌdʒɹə. "ðoʊ - fəɹ kəmplitli dɪfɹən ɹizənz  - aɪd laɪk tə teɪk ðiz plænz wɪð mi ən kip əm seɪf."

"All right," he said again. He looked back at Aludra. "Though - for completely different reasons  - I'd like to take these plans with me and keep them safe."

"kəmplitli dɪfɹən ɹizənz?" laɪlwɪn æskt ɪn ə flæt toʊn, əz ɪf sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ ɪnsəlt.

"Completely different reasons?" Leilwin asked in a flat tone, as if searching for another insult.

"jɛs," mæt sɛd. "ðoʊz ɹizənz biɪŋ ðəɾ aɪ doʊnt wɑn əm hɪɹ wən ɑlʌdʒɹə tæps wʌn ə ðoʊz naɪtfloʊɝz ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ ən bloʊz hɝsɛlf hæfweɪ tə tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp!"

"Yes," Mat said. "Those reasons being that I don't want them here when Aludra taps one of those nightflowers the wrong way and blows herself halfway to Tarwin's Gap!"

ɑlʌdʒɹə tʃʌkəld ət ðæt, ðoʊ laɪlwɪn lʊkt əfɛndəɾ əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd nɑt tə əfɛn ə sintʃæn. ðɛm ən ðə blʌɾi il. stʃɹeɪnʒ haʊ ɑpəzət ðeɪ kəd bi ɪn mɛni weɪz, jɛt ðə seɪm ɪn soʊ mɛni ʌðɝz.

Aludra chuckled at that, though Leilwin looked offended again. It was hard not to offend a Seanchan. Them and the bloody Aiel. Strange how opposite they could be in many ways, yet the same in so many others.

"ju meɪ teɪk ðə plænz, mæt," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd. "soʊ lɔŋ əz jə kip əm ɪn ðət tʃɹʌŋk wɪð jəɹ ɡoʊld. ðəɾ ɪz wʌn əbdʒɛkt ɪn ðɪs kæmp ðət wɪl ɹəsiv ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ətɛnʃən fɹəm ju."

"You may take the plans, Mat," Aludra said. "So long as you keep them in that trunk with your gold. That is one object in this camp that will receive the greatest attention from you."

"θæŋk jə kaɪnli," hi sɛd, stupɪŋ tə ɡæðɝ ʌp ðə peɪdʒəz, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə veɪld ɪnsəlt. hædn ðeɪ dʒʌs meɪɾ ʌp? blʌɾi wʊmən. "baɪ ðə weɪ, aɪ nɪɹli fɝɡɑt. dʒju noʊ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt kɹɔsboʊz, ɑlʌdʒɹə?"

"Thank you kindly," he said, stooping to gather up the pages, ignoring the veiled insult. Hadn't they just made up? Bloody woman. "By the way, I nearly forgot. Do you know anything about crossbows, Aludra?"

"kɹɔsboʊz?" ʃi æskt.

"Crossbows?" she asked.

"jɛs," mæt sɛd, stækɪŋ ðə peɪpɝz. "aɪ fɪɡjɝ ðəɹ ʃəd bi ə weɪ tə meɪk əm loʊd fæstɝ.

"Yes," Mat said, stacking the papers. "I figure there should be a way to make them load faster.

jə noʊ, laɪk ðoʊz nu kɹæŋks, oʊnli meɪbi wɪð səm kaɪndə spɹɪŋ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ. meɪbi ə kɹæŋk jə kəd twɪst wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ tə loʊɝ ðə wɛpən fɝst."

You know, like those new cranks, only maybe with some kind of spring or something. Maybe a crank you could twist without having to lower the weapon first."

"ðɪs ɪz hɑɹdli maɪ ɛɹiə ʌv ɛkspɝtiz, mæt," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd.

"This is hardly my area of expertise, Mat," Aludra said.

"aɪ noʊ. bʌt jəɹ smɑɹɾ əbaʊt θɪŋz laɪk ðɪs, ən meɪbi. . . ."

"I know. But you're smart about things like this, and maybe. . . ."

"ju wɪl əv tə faɪn sʌmwʌn ɛls," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə pɪk ʌp ənʌðɝ hæf-fɪnɪʃt naɪtfloʊɝ. "aɪ æm fɑɹ tu bɪzi."

"You will have to find someone else," Aludra said, turning to pick up another half-finished nightflower. "I am far too busy."

mæt ɹitʃt ʌp ʌndɝ ɪz hæt, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "ðæt - "

Mat reached up under his hat, scratching his head. "That - "

"mæt!" ə vɔɪs kɔld. "mæt, juv ɡɑt tə kʌm wɪð mi!" mæt tɝn əz oʊlvɝ ɹæn ɪndə ɑlʌdʒɹəz kæmp. beɪl hɛld aʊɾ ə wɔɹnɪŋ hænd, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs oʊlvɝ dʒʌst ɹæn ɹaɪt bɪniθ ɪt.

"Mat!" a voice called. "Mat, you've got to come with me!" Mat turned as Olver ran into Aludra's camp. Bayle held out a warning hand, but of course Olver just ran right beneath it.

mæt stʃɹeɪɾənd ʌp. "wʌt?" hi æskt.

Mat straightened up. "What?" he asked.

"sʌmwʌnz kʌm tə ðə kæmp," oʊlvɝ sɛd, ɪksaɪtmən peɪntɪŋ ɪz fitʃɝz. ən ðoʊz fitʃɝz wɝ ə saɪt. ɪɹz ðət wɝ tu bɪɡ fəɹ ɪz hɛd, noʊz ðət wɑz skwɑʃt daʊn, maʊθ ðət wɑz tu waɪd. ɑn ə tʃaɪld ɪz eɪdʒ, ði ʌɡlinəs wɑz ɛndiɹɪŋ. hiɾ əv noʊ sətʃ lʌk wən i ɡɹu oʊldɝ.

"Someone's come to the camp," Olver said, excitement painting his features. And those features were a sight. Ears that were too big for his head, nose that was squashed down, mouth that was too wide. On a child his age, the ugliness was endearing. He'd have no such luck when he grew older.

meɪbi ðə mɛn ɪn kæmp wɝ ɹaɪt tə bi titʃɪŋ ɪm wɛpənz. wɪð ə feɪs laɪk ðæt, hid bɛɾɝ noʊ haʊ tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf.

Maybe the men in camp were right to be teaching him weapons. With a face like that, he'd better know how to defend himself.

"weɪt, sloʊ daʊn," mæt sɛd, tʌkɪŋ ɑlʌdʒɹəz plænz ɪndə hɪz bɛlt. "sʌmwʌnz kʌm? hu? waɪ dʒju nid mi?"

"Wait, slow down," Mat said, tucking Aludra's plans into his belt. "Someone's come? Who? Why do you need me?"

"tælmɑnz sɛn mi tə fɛtʃ ju," oʊlvɝ sɛd. "hi θɪŋks ʃiz sʌmwʌn ɪmpɔɹɾənt. sɛd tə tɛl jə ʃiz ɡɑt səm peɪdʒəz wɪð jəɹ pɪktʃɝ ɑn ðɛm, ən ðət ʃiz ɡɑɾ ə 'dɪstɪŋktɪv feɪs,' wʌtɛvɝ ðət minz. ðæt. . . ."

"Talmanes sent me to fetch you," Olver said. "He thinks she's someone important. Said to tell you she's got some pages with your picture on them, and that she's got a 'distinctive face,' whatever that means. That. . . ."

oʊlvɝ kəntɪnjud, bʌt mæt hæd stɑp lɪsnɪŋ. hi nɑɾəd tə ɑlʌdʒɹə ən ði ʌðɝz, ðən tʃɹɑɾəd aʊɾ ə hɝ kæmp, pæs ðə ʃits ən aʊɾ ɪndə ðə wʊdz pɹɑpɝ. oʊlvɝ tæɡd əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn əz mæt hɝid tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kæmp.

Olver continued, but Mat had stopped listening. He nodded to Aludra and the others, then trotted out of her camp, past the sheets and out into the woods proper. Olver tagged along behind as Mat hurried to the front of the camp.

ðɛɹ, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə ʃɔɹt-lɛɡəd waɪt mɛɹ, wɑz ə pʌdʒi wʊmən wɪð ə ɡɹændmʌðɝli ɛɹ, ə bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs, ən stʃɹiks ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, wɪtʃ wɑz pʊl bæk ɪn ə bʌn. ʃi wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz, tælmɑnz ən mændəvwɪn stændɪŋ dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, laɪk tu stoʊn pɪlɝz bɑɹɪŋ ɛntʃɹəns tə ə hɑɹbɝ.

There, sitting on a short-legged white mare, was a pudgy woman with a grandmotherly air, a brown dress, and streaks of gray in her hair, which was pulled back in a bun. She was surrounded by a group of soldiers, Talmanes and Mandevwin standing directly in front of her, like two stone pillars barring entrance to a harbor.

ðə wʊmən hæɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs, ən ən eɪdʒɪŋ wɔɹɾɝ stʊd bɪsaɪɾ əɹ hɔɹs. ðoʊ hi hæd ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ, ðə stɑki mæn ɪɡzuɾɪd ðət sɛns ə deɪnʒɝ ðəɾ ɔl wɔɹɾɝz hæd. hi stʌɾid ðə bænz soʊlʒɝz wɪð ənjildɪŋ aɪz, ɑɹmz foʊldəd.

The woman had an Aes Sedai face, and an aging Warder stood beside her horse. Though he had graying hair, the stocky man exuded that sense of danger that all Warders had. He studied the Band's soldiers with unyielding eyes, arms folded.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ smaɪld ət mæt əz i tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp. "ɑ, vɛɹi naɪs," ʃi sɛd pɹɪmli. "juv ɡɹoʊn pɹɑmp sɪns wi læs pɑɹɾəd, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən."

The Aes Sedai smiled at Mat as he trotted up. "Ah, very nice," she said primly. "You've grown prompt since we last parted, Matrim Cauthon."

"vɛɹɪn," mæt sɛd, pæntɪŋ slaɪtli fɹəm ðə ɹʌn. hi ɡlænst ət tælmɑnz u hɛld ʌp ə ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ, wʌn ə ðoʊz ɪmpɹɪntɪd wɪð mæts feɪs. "juv dɪskʌvɝd ðət sʌmwʌnz bɪn dɪstʃɹɪbjuɾɪŋ pɪktʃɝz ə mi ɪn tʃɹʌstɛɹ?"

"Verin," Mat said, panting slightly from the run. He glanced at Talmanes who held up a sheet of paper, one of those imprinted with Mat's face. "You've discovered that someone's been distributing pictures of me in Trustair?"

ʃi læft. "ju kəd seɪ ðæt."

She laughed. "You could say that."

hi lʊkt ət hɝ, miɾɪŋ ðoʊz dɑɹk bɹaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ aɪz. "blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz," hi mʌɾɝd. "ɪt wɑz ju, wɑzn ɪt? jəɹ ðə wʌn huz bɪn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi!"

He looked at her, meeting those dark brown Aes Sedai eyes. "Blood and bloody ashes," he muttered. "It was you, wasn't it? You're the one who's been looking for me!"

"fɔɹ səm taɪm, aɪ maɪɾ æd," vɛɹɪn sɛd laɪtli. "æn ɹæðɝ əɡɛns maɪ wɪl."

"For some time, I might add," Verin said lightly. "And rather against my will."

mæt kloʊzd ɪz aɪz. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ ɪz ɪntʃɹəkət plæn fəɹ ðə ɹeɪd. bɝn ɪt! ən ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd plæn, tu. "haʊd jə faɪn aɪ wɑz hɪɹ?" hi æskt, oʊpənɪŋ ɪz aɪz.

Mat closed his eyes. So much for his intricate plan for the raid. Burn it! And it was a good plan, too. "How'd you find I was here?" he asked, opening his eyes.

"ə kaɪn mɝtʃən keɪm tə mi ɪn tʃɹʌstɛɹ ən aʊɝ əɡoʊ ən ɪkspleɪn ðət hid dʒʌs hæɾ ə naɪs miɾɪŋ wɪð ju, ən ðət jud peɪɾ ɪm hænsəmli fəɹ ə skɛtʃ ə tʃɹʌstɛɹ. aɪ fɪɡjɝd ðəɾ aɪd spɛɹ ðə pʊɹ taʊn ən əsɔl baɪ jəɹ . . . əsoʊsiɪts ən dʒʌs kʌm tə jə maɪsɛlf."

"A kind merchant came to me in Trustair an hour ago and explained that he'd just had a nice meeting with you, and that you'd paid him handsomely for a sketch of Trustair. I figured that I'd spare the poor town an assault by your . . . associates and just come to you myself."

"æn aʊɝ əɡoʊ?" mæt sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "bʌt tʃɹʌstɛɹ ɪz stɪl hæf ə deɪz mɑɹtʃ əweɪ!"

"An hour ago?" Mat said, frowning. "But Trustair is still half a day's march away!"

"ɪndiɾ ɪɾ ɪz." vɛɹɪn smaɪld.

"Indeed it is." Verin smiled.

"bɝn mi," hi sɛd. "juv ɡɑt tʃɹævlɪŋ, doʊn ju?"

"Burn me," he said. "You've got Traveling, don't you?"

hɝ smaɪl dipənd. "aɪ sɝmaɪz ðət jəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt tə ændɝ wɪð ðɪs ɑɹmi, mæstɝ kɔθən."

Her smile deepened. "I surmise that you're trying to get to Andor with this army, Master Cauthon."

"ðæt dɪpɛnz," mæt sɛd. "kæn jə teɪk əs ðɛɹ?"

"That depends," Mat said. "Can you take us there?"

"ɪn ə vɛɹi ʃɔɹt taɪm," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ kəɾ əv jəɹ mɛn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn baɪ ivnɪŋ."

"In a very short time," Verin said. "I could have your men in Caemlyn by evening."

laɪt! twɛnti deɪz ʃeɪvd ɔf ɪz mɑɹtʃ? meɪbi hi kəd ɡɛɾ ɑlʌdʒɹəz dʒɹæɡənz ɪndə pɹədʌkʃən sun! hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, aɪɪŋ vɛɹɪn, fɔɹsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə kənteɪn ɪz ɪksaɪtmənt. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə kɑst wən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɪnvɑlvd.

Light! Twenty days shaved off his march? Maybe he could get Aludra's dragons into production soon! He hesitated, eyeing Verin, forcing himself to contain his excitement. There was always a cost when Aes Sedai were involved.

"wʌt dʒju wɑnt?" hi æskt.

"What do you want?" he asked.

"fɹæŋkli," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd, saɪɪŋ slaɪtli. "wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən, ɪz tə bi kʌt fɹi fɹəm jəɹ tɑvɝən wɛb! dʒju noʊ haʊ lɔŋ juv fɔɹs mi tə weɪɾ ɪn ðiz maʊntənz?"

"Frankly," she replied, sighing slightly. "What I want, Matrim Cauthon, is to be cut free from your ta'veren web! Do you know how long you've forced me to wait in these mountains?"

"fɔɹst? "

"Forced? "

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd. "kʌm, wɪv mʌtʃ tə dɪskʌs." ʃi flɪkt əɹ ɹeɪnz, muvɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs ɪndə kæmp, ən tælmɑnz ən mændəvwɪn ɹɪlʌktənli stɛpt əsaɪd, lɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɪn. mæt dʒɔɪn ðə tu ʌv ðɛm, wɑtʃɪŋ əz ʃi meɪd stʃɹeɪt fəɹ ðə kʊk faɪɝz.

"Yes," she said. "Come, we have much to discuss." She flicked her reins, moving her horse into camp, and Talmanes and Mandevwin reluctantly stepped aside, letting her in. Mat joined the two of them, watching as she made straight for the cook fires.

"aɪ ɡɛs ðəɹ woʊn bi ə ɹeɪd," tælmɑnz sɛd. hi dɪdn saʊn sæd.

"I guess there won't be a raid," Talmanes said. He didn't sound sad.

mændəvwɪn fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪz aɪ pætʃ. "dʌz ðɪs min aɪ kən ɡoʊ bæk tə maɪ pʊɹ eɪdʒd ænt?"

Mandevwin fingered his eye patch. "Does this mean I can go back to my poor aged aunt?"

"ju hæv noʊ pʊɹ eɪdʒd ænt," mæt ɡɹaʊld. "kʌm ɑn, lɛts hɪɹ wʌt ðə wʊmən əz tə seɪ."

"You have no poor aged aunt," Mat growled. "Come on, let's hear what the woman has to say."

"faɪn," mændəvwɪn sɛd. "bʌt nɛks taɪm, aɪ ɡɛt tə bi ðə wɔɹɾɝ, ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt?"

"Fine," Mandevwin said. "But next time, I get to be the Warder, all right, Mat?"

mæt dʒʌst saɪd, hɝiɪŋ æftɝ vɛɹɪn.

Mat just sighed, hurrying after Verin.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾifaɪv

CHAPTER 35

eɪ heɪloʊ ʌv blæknəs ðə kul si bɹiz wɑʃt əkɹɔs ɹænd ðə moʊmən i ɹoʊd θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðət sɑft, fɛðɝlaɪk wɪn kæɹid wɪð ɪt ðə sɛns ʌv ə θaʊzən kʊk faɪɝz skæɾɝd θɹu ðə sɪɾi ʌv fɑlm, hiɾɪŋ mɔɹnɪŋ stuz.

A Halo of Blackness The cool sea breeze washed across Rand the moment he rode through the gateway. That soft, featherlike wind carried with it the scents of a thousand cook fires scattered through the city of Falme, heating morning stews.

ɹænd ɹeɪn ɪn teɪdeɪʃɝ, ʌnpɹipɛɹd fəɹ ðə mɛmɹiz ðoʊz sɛns wəd kæɹi wɪð ðɛm.

Rand reined in Tai'daishar, unprepared for the memories those scents would carry with them.

mɛmɹiz ʌv ə taɪm wən hid stɪl bɪn ənsɝɾən əbaʊɾ ɪz ɹoʊl ɪn ðə wɝld. mɛmɹiz ʌv ə taɪm wən mæt hæd kɑnstənli ɹɪbd ɪm fəɹ wɛɹɪŋ faɪn koʊts, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðət ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə əvɔɪd ðɛm. mɛmɹiz ʌv ə taɪm wən i hæd bɪn əʃeɪmd ə ðə bænɝz ðət naʊ flæp bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi hæd wʌns ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn kipɪŋ əm hɪɾən, əz ɪf ɪn duɪŋ soʊ hi kəd haɪd fɹəm ɪz oʊn feɪt.

Memories of a time when he'd still been uncertain about his role in the world. Memories of a time when Mat had constantly ribbed him for wearing fine coats, despite the fact that Rand tried to avoid them. Memories of a time when he had been ashamed of the banners that now flapped behind him. He had once insisted on keeping them hidden, as if in doing so he could hide from his own fate.

ðə pɹəsɛʃən weɪɾəd fəɹ hɪm, bʌkəlz kɹikɪŋ, hɔɹsəz snɔɹɾɪŋ. ɹænd hæd vɪzəɾəd fɑlm wʌns, bɹifli. bæk ɪn ðoʊz deɪz, hi hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə steɪ ɛniwɛɹ fəɹ lɔŋ. hid spɛn ðoʊz mʌnθs iðɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ əɹ biɪŋ tʃeɪst. feɪn hæd lɛɾ ɪm tə fɑlm, bɛɹɪŋ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ən ðə ɹubi dæɡɝ tə wɪtʃ mæt hæd bɪn baʊnd. ðə kʌlɝz flæʃt əɡɛn, əz i θɔɾ ə mæt, bʌt ɹænd ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. fəɹ ðiz fju moʊməns, hi wɑzn ɪn ðə pɹɛzənt.

The procession waited for him, buckles creaking, horses snorting. Rand had visited Falme once, briefly. Back in those days, he hadn't been able to stay anywhere for long. He'd spent those months either chasing or being chased. Fain had led him to Falme, bearing the Horn of Valere and the ruby dagger to which Mat had been bound. The colors flashed again, as he thought of Mat, but Rand ignored them. For these few moments, he wasn't in the present.

fɑlm mɑɹkt ə tɝnɪŋ pɔɪn ɪn ɹændz laɪf əz pɹoʊfaʊn əz ðə wʌn ðət hæd leɪɾɝ əkɝɾ ɪn ðə bæɹən lænz ə ði il, wən i hæd pɹuvən hɪmsɛlf tə bi ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn. æftɝ fɑlm, ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ mɔɹ haɪɾɪŋ, noʊ mɔɹ faɪɾɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz. ðɪs wɑz ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hid fɝst æknɑlɪdʒ hɪmsɛlf əz ə kɪlɝ, ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hid fɝst ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ ə deɪnʒɝ i wɑz tə ðoʊz ɝaʊn hɪm. hid tʃɹaɪd tə liv əm ɔl bɪhaɪnd. ðeɪd kʌm æftɝ hɪm.

Falme marked a turning point in Rand's life as profound as the one that had later occurred in the barren lands of the Aiel, when he had proven himself to be the Car'a'carn. After Falme, there had been no more hiding, no more fighting what he was. This was the place where he'd first acknowledged himself as a killer, the place where he'd first realized what a danger he was to those around him. He'd tried to leave them all behind. They'd come after him.

ət fɑlm, ðə ʃɛpɝd bɔɪ hæd bɝnd, hɪz æʃəz skæɾɝd ən bloʊn əweɪ baɪ ðoʊz oʊʃən wɪnz. fɹəm ðoʊz æʃəz, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd ɹɪzən.

At Falme, the shepherd boy had burned, his ashes scattered and blown away by those ocean winds. From those ashes, the Dragon Reborn had risen.

ɹænd nid teɪdeɪʃɝ fɔɹwɝd, ən ðə pɹəsɛʃən bɪɡæn əɡɛn. hi hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən ə ʃɔɹt ɹaɪd fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, hoʊpfəli aʊɾ ʌv aɪsaɪɾ ə deɪmeɪn. ʌv kɔɹs i hæɾ æʃəmən kɹieɪɾɪŋ ɪt - ðɛɹbaɪ haɪɾɪŋ ðə wivz fɹəm wɪmən - bʌɾ i dɪdnt wɑnə ɡɪv əm ɛni kluz əbaʊt tʃɹævlɪŋ. ðə sintʃæn ɪnəbɪlɪɾi tə tʃɹævəl wɑz wʌn ə hɪz ɡɹeɪɾəst ædvæntɪdʒɪz.

Rand kneed Tai'daishar forward, and the procession began again. He had ordered the gateway opened a short ride from the city, hopefully out of eyesight of damane. Of course he had Asha'man creating it - thereby hiding the weaves from women - but he didn't want to give them any clues about Traveling. The Seanchan inability to Travel was one of his greatest advantages.

fɑlm ɪtsɛlf stʊɾ ɑn ə smɔl spɪɾ ə lænd - toʊmən hɛd - dʒʌɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. haɪ klɪfs əlɔŋ boʊθ saɪdz bɹoʊk ðə weɪvz, kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə sɑft, dɪstən ɹɔɹ. ðə sɪɾiz dɑɹk stoʊn bɪldɪŋz kʌvɝd ðə pənɪnsələ laɪk ɹɑks ɑn ðə bɛɾ ʌv ə ɹɪvɝ. moʊst wɝ skwɑt, wʌn-stɔɹi bɪldɪŋz - bɪlt waɪd, əz ɪf ði ɪnhæbəɾənts ɪkspɛktəd ðə weɪvz tə wɑʃ ʌp oʊvɝ ðə klɪfs ən kɹæʃ əɡɛns ðɛɹ hoʊmz. ðə ɡɹæslænz hɪɹ dɪdnt ʃoʊ əz mʌtʃ wɪðɝɪŋ əz ðə læn dɪd tə ðə nɔɹθ, bʌt ðə nu spɹɪŋ ɡɹæs wɑz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə lʊk jɛloʊ ən wɑn, əz ɪf ðə bleɪdz ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd poʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz aʊɾ ə ðə sɔɪl.

Falme itself stood on a small spit of land - Toman Head - jutting out into the Aryth Ocean. High cliffs along both sides broke the waves, creating a soft, distant roar. The city's dark stone buildings covered the peninsula like rocks on the bed of a river. Most were squat, one-story buildings - built wide, as if the inhabitants expected the waves to wash up over the cliffs and crash against their homes. The grasslands here didn't show as much withering as the land did to the north, but the new spring grass was starting to look yellow and wan, as if the blades regretted poking their heads out of the soil.

ðə pənɪnsələ sləp daʊn tə ə nætʃɹəl hɑɹbɝ, ən numɝəs sintʃæn ʃɪps leɪ əɾ æŋkɝ ðɛɹ.

The peninsula sloped down to a natural harbor, and numerous Seanchan ships lay at anchor there.

sintʃæn flæɡz flu, pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ ðɪs sɪɾi ə pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ ɛmpaɪɝ; ðə bænɝ ðət flʌɾɝd haɪəst əbʌv ðə sɪɾi dɪspleɪɾ ə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪt, klʌtʃɪŋ θɹi boʊls ə laɪtnɪŋ. ɪt wɑz fɹɪnd wɪð blu.

Seanchan flags flew, proclaiming this city a part of their empire; the banner that fluttered highest above the city displayed a golden hawk in flight, clutching three bolts of lightning. It was fringed with blue.

ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹitʃɝz ðə sintʃæn hæd bɹɔt fɹəm ðɛɹ saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən muv θɹu dɪstən stʃɹits, tu fɑɹ ɔf fəɹ ɹænd tə meɪk aʊt dɪteɪlz. ɹeɪkən flu ɪn ðə skaɪ; ðə sintʃæn əpɛɹənli hæɾ ə lɑɹdʒ steɪbəl ə ðɛm hɪɹ. toʊmən hɛd wɑz dʒʌst saʊθ ʌv ɑɹæd dumən, ən ðɪs sɪɾi wɑz noʊ daʊɾ ə meɪdʒɝ steɪdʒɪŋ ɛɹiə fəɹ ðə sintʃæn kæmpeɪn tə ðə nɔɹθ.

The strange creatures the Seanchan had brought from their side of the ocean moved through distant streets, too far off for Rand to make out details. Raken flew in the sky; the Seanchan apparently had a large stable of them here. Toman Head was just south of Arad Doman, and this city was no doubt a major staging area for the Seanchan campaign to the north.

ðət kɑŋkwɛst wəɾ ɛn tədeɪ. ɹænd hæd tə meɪk pis, hæd tə kənvɪns ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz tə kɔl ɔf əɹ ɑɹmiz. ðət pis wəd bi ðə kɑm bɪfɔɹ ə stɔɹm. hi wʊdn bi pɹətɛktɪŋ ɪz pipəl fɹəm wɔɹ; dʒʌs pɹəzɝvɪŋ əm soʊ ðət ðeɪ kəd daɪ fəɹ ɪm ɛlswɛɹ. bʌɾ i wəd də wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn.

That conquest would end today. Rand had to make peace, had to convince the Daughter of the Nine Moons to call off her armies. That peace would be the calm before a storm. He wouldn't be protecting his people from war; just preserving them so that they could die for him elsewhere. But he would do what had to be done.

nɪneɪiv ɹoʊɾ ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɪm əz ðeɪ kəntɪnjud təwɔɹd fɑlm. hɝ nit dʒɹɛs ə blu ən waɪt wɑz kʌɾ æftɝ ðə dəmɑni fæʃən, bʌt meɪɾ ʌv ə mʌtʃ θɪkɝ - ən fɑɹ mɔɹ mɑɾəst - mətɪɹiəl. ʃi sim tə bi ədɑptɪŋ fæʃənz fɹəm ɝaʊn ðə wɝld, wɛɹɪŋ dʒɹɛsəz fɹəm ðə sɪɾiz ʃi vɪzəɾəd, bʌɾ ɪmpoʊzɪŋ əɹ oʊn sɛns ʌv wʌt wɑz pɹɑpɝ əpɑn ðɛm. wʌns, pɝhæps, ɹænd wʊɾə faʊn ðɪs əmjuzɪŋ. ðəɾ ɪmoʊʃən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sim pɑsəbəl fəɹ hɪm. hi kəɾ oʊnli fil ðə koʊl stɪlnəs ɪnsaɪd, ðə stɪlnəs ðət kæpt ə faʊntən ə fɹoʊzən ɹeɪdʒ.

Nynaeve rode up beside him as they continued toward Falme. Her neat dress of blue and white was cut after the Domani fashion, but made of a much thicker - and far more modest - material. She seemed to be adopting fashions from around the world, wearing dresses from the cities she visited, but imposing her own sense of what was proper upon them. Once, perhaps, Rand would have found this amusing. That emotion no longer seemed possible for him. He could only feel the cold stillness inside, the stillness that capped a fountain of frozen rage.

hi wəd kip ðə ɹeɪdʒ ən stɪlnəs bæləns lɔŋ ɪnʌf. hi hæd tə.

He would keep the rage and stillness balanced long enough. He had to.

"æn soʊ wi ɹɪtɝn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. hɝ mʌltɪkʌlɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil dʒuəlɹi sʌmwʌt spɔɪl ðə lʊk ə hɝ nitli teɪlɝd dʒɹɛs.

"And so we return," Nynaeve said. Her multicolor ter'angreal jewelry somewhat spoiled the look of her neatly tailored dress.

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd.

"Yes," Rand said.

"aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə læs taɪm wi wɝ hɪɹ," ʃi sɛɾ aɪdli. "sʌtʃ keɪɑs, sətʃ mædnəs. ən ət ði ɛn ʌv ɪɾ ɔl, wi faʊn jə wɪð ðət waʊn ɪn jəɹ saɪd."

"I remember the last time we were here," she said idly. "Such chaos, such madness. And at the end of it all, we found you with that wound in your side."

"jɛs," ɹænd wɪspɝd. hi hæɾ ɝn ðət fɝst ə hɪz ənhiləbəl wunz hɪɹ, faɪɾɪŋ ɪʃəml ɪn ðə skaɪz əbʌv ðə sɪɾi. ðə waʊnd ɡɹu wɔɹm əz i θɔɾ ʌv ɪt. wɔɹm, ən peɪnfəl. hi hæd stɑɹɾəd ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðət peɪn əz ən oʊl fɹɛnd, ə ɹimaɪndɝ ðəɾ i wɑz əlaɪv.

"Yes," Rand whispered. He had earned that first of his unhealable wounds here, fighting Ishamael in the skies above the city. The wound grew warm as he thought of it. Warm, and painful. He had started regarding that pain as an old friend, a reminder that he was alive.

"aɪ sɔ jə ʌp ɪn ði ɛɹ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ dɪdn bɪliv ɪt. aɪ . . . tʃɹaɪd tə hil ðət waʊnd, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz stɪl blɑk ðɛn, ən kʊdn sʌmən ði æŋɡɝ. mɪn wʊdn liv jəɹ saɪd."

"I saw you up in the air," Nynaeve said. "I didn't believe it. I . . . tried to Heal that wound, but I was still blocked then, and couldn't summon the anger. Min wouldn't leave your side."
