Min hadn't come with him this day. She remained close to him, but something had changed between them. Just as he had always feared that it would. When she looked at him, he knew she saw him killing her.

dʒʌst ə fju wiks bɪfɔɹ, hi wʊdn əv bɪn eɪbəl tə kip əɹ fɹəm əkʌmpəniɪŋ hɪm, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt. naʊ ʃi ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd wɪθaʊɾ ə sɪŋɡəl pɹoʊɾɛst.

Just a few weeks before, he wouldn't have been able to keep her from accompanying him, no matter what. Now she remained behind without a single protest.

koʊlnəs. ɪt wəd bi oʊvɝ sun. noʊ ɹum fəɹ ɹəɡɹɛɾ əɹ sɑɹoʊ.

Coldness. It would be over soon. No room for regret or sorrow.

ði il ɹæn əhɛd tə tʃɛk fəɹ ən æmbʊʃ. mɛni ʌv əm wɔɹ ðə ɹɛd hɛdbænz. ɹænd wɑznt wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ən æmbʊʃ. ðə sintʃæn wəd nɑt bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪm, nɑɾ ənlɛs ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən ɪn ðɛɹ mɪdst.

The Aiel ran ahead to check for an ambush. Many of them wore the red headbands. Rand wasn't worried about an ambush. The Seanchan would not betray him, not unless there was another Forsaken in their midst.

ɹænd ɹitʃt daʊn, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ i wɔɹ əɾ ɪz weɪst. ɪt wɑz ðə kɝvd wʌn, wɪð ðə skæbɝɾ ə blæk, peɪntəd wɪð ðə twɪstɪŋ dʒɹæɡən, ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld. fəɹ mɔɹ ɹizənz ðən wʌn, ɪt meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə ðə læs taɪm i hæd bɪn ɪn fɑlm.

Rand reached down, touching the sword he wore at his waist. It was the curved one, with the scabbard of black, painted with the twisting dragon, red and gold. For more reasons than one, it made him think of the last time he had been in Falme.

"aɪ kɪld ə mæn wɪð ə sɔɹd fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "aɪv nɛvɝ spoʊkən ʌv ɪt. hi wɑz ə sintʃæn lɔɹd, ə bleɪdmæstɝ. vɛɹɪn hæd toʊl mi nɑt tə tʃænəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi, soʊ aɪ feɪst ɪm wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ oʊnli. aɪ bit hɪm. kɪl hɪm."

"I killed a man with a sword for the first time in this city," Rand said softly. "I've never spoken of it. He was a Seanchan lord, a blademaster. Verin had told me not to channel in the city, so I faced him with the sword only. I beat him. Killed him."

nɪneɪiv ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "soʊ jə də hæv ə ɹaɪt tə kæɹi ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd."

Nynaeve raised an eyebrow. "So you do have a right to carry a heron-mark blade."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðɛɹ wɝ noʊ wɪtnəsəz. mæt ən hʊɹɪn wɝ faɪɾɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ. ðeɪ sɔ mi ɹaɪɾ æftɝ ðə faɪt, bʌt dɪd nɑt wɪtnəs ðə kɪlɪŋ bloʊ."

Rand shook his head. "There were no witnesses. Mat and Hurin were fighting elsewhere. They saw me right after the fight, but did not witness the killing blow."

"wʌt də wɪtnəsəz mæɾɝ?" ʃi skɔft. "ju dɪfiɾəd ə bleɪdmæstɝ, soʊ jə ɑɹ wʌn. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ ɪt wɑz sin baɪ ʌðɝz ɪz ɪmətɪɹiəl."

"What do witnesses matter?" she scoffed. "You defeated a blademaster, so you are one. Whether or not it was seen by others is immaterial."

hi lʊkt ət hɝ. "waɪ kæɹi ðə hɛɹən mɑɹk ɪf nɑt tə bi sin baɪ ʌðɝz, nɪneɪiv?"

He looked at her. "Why carry the heron mark if not to be seen by others, Nynaeve?"

ʃi dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd. əhɛd, dʒʌst aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, ðə sintʃæn hæɾ ɪɹɛktəɾ ə stʃɹaɪpt pəvɪljən ə blæk ən waɪt. ðəɹ əpɪɹd tə bi hʌnʒɹədz ə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn pɛɹz sɝaʊndɪŋ ði oʊpən- saɪɾəd tɛnt, deɪmeɪn wɛɹɪŋ ðə dɪstɪŋktɪv ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs, sʌldəm wɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz ə ɹɛɾ ən blu wɪð ðə laɪtnɪŋ boʊlt ɑn ðə bɹɛst. ɹænd hæd bɹɔɾ oʊnli ə fju tʃænlɝz: nɪneɪiv, θɹi waɪz wʌnz, kɔɹəl, nɛɹɪʃmə, flɪn. ə fɹækʃən ʌv wʌɾ i kəɾ æksɛs, ivən wɪθaʊt tɝnɪŋ tə hɪz fɔɹsɪz steɪʃən ɪn ði ist.

She didn't respond. Ahead, just outside of the city, the Seanchan had erected a striped pavilion of black and white. There appeared to be hundreds of sul'dam and damane pairs surrounding the open- sided tent, damane wearing the distinctive gray dress, sul'dam wearing their dresses of red and blue with the lightning bolt on the breast. Rand had brought only a few channelers: Nynaeve, three Wise Ones, Corele, Narishma, Flinn. A fraction of what he could access, even without turning to his forces stationed in the east.

bʌt noʊ, ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ tə bɹɪŋ oʊnli ə toʊkən ɡɑɹd, tə lʊk əz ðoʊ hi keɪm ɪn pis. ɪf ðɪs miɾɪŋ tɝn ɪndə ə bæɾəl, ɹændz oʊnli hoʊp wəd bi ə kwɪk ɪskeɪp vaɪə ɡeɪtweɪ. iðɝ ðət . . .

But no, it was better to bring only a token guard, to look as though he came in peace. If this meeting turned into a battle, Rand's only hope would be a quick escape via gateway. Either that . . .

əɹ də sʌmθɪŋ tə ɛn ðə faɪt hɪmsɛlf.

or do something to end the fight himself.

ðə fɪɡjɝin ə ðə mæn hoʊldɪŋ əlɔf ðə sfɪɹ hʌŋ fɹəm ðə sæɾəl bɪfɔɹ hɪm. wɪð ɪt, hi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə stæn əɡɛnst ə hʌnʒɹəd deɪmeɪn. tu hʌnʒɹəd. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə paʊɝ hid hɛld wən klɛnzɪŋ seɪɾɪn. ɪt hæd bɪn ðə paʊɝ tə lɛvəl sɪɾiz, tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɛni hu stʊɾ əɡɛns hɪm.

The figurine of the man holding aloft the sphere hung from the saddle before him. With it, he might be able to stand against a hundred damane. Two hundred. He could remember the Power he'd held when cleansing saidin. It had been the Power to level cities, to destroy any who stood against him.

noʊ. ɪt wʊdn tɝn tə ðæt. hi kʊdn əfɔɹd tə lɛɾ ɪt tɝn tə ðæt. ʃʊɹli ðə sintʃæn nu ðəɾ ətækɪŋ ɪm wəd lɛd tə dɪzæstɝ. ɹænd hæd kʌm tə mit wɪð əm əɡɛn, əwɛɹ ðəɾ ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ ɪn ðɛɹ ɹæŋks hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kæptʃɝ əɹ kɪl hɪm. ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə si hɪz sənsɛɹəɾi.

No. It wouldn't turn to that. He couldn't afford to let it turn to that. Surely the Seanchan knew that attacking him would lead to disaster. Rand had come to meet with them again, aware that a traitor in their ranks had tried to capture or kill him. They would have to see his sincerity.

bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ dɪdnt. . . . hi ɹitʃt daʊn ən ɡɹæsp ði æksɛs ki, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs, ən slɪpt ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz oʊvɝsaɪzd aʊɾɝ koʊt pɑkət. ðɛn, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi stɛɾid hɪmsɛlf ən sɔt ðə vɔɪd. ðɛɹ, hi siz ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

But if they didn't. . . . He reached down and grasped the access key, just in case, and slipped it into his oversized outer coat pocket. Then, taking a deep breath, he steadied himself and sought the void. There, he seized the One Power.

nɔziə ən dɪzinəs θɹɛɾənd tə tɔs ɪm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi wɑbəld, lɛɡz ɡɹɪpɪŋ teɪdeɪʃɝ, hæn klʌtʃɪŋ ði æksɛs ki ɪn ɪts pɑkət. hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd, luz θɝɪn ɹaʊzd. ðə mædmæn skɹæmbəl fəɹ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪt wɑz ə dɛspɹɪt faɪt, ən wən ɹænd faɪnəli wʌn, hi faʊn ðət hid slʌmpt ɪn ɪz sæɾəl.

Nausea and dizziness threatened to toss him to the ground. He wobbled, legs gripping Tai'daishar, hand clutching the access key in its pocket. He gritted his teeth. In the back of his mind, Lews Therin roused. The madman scrambled for the One Power. It was a desperate fight, and when Rand finally won, he found that he'd slumped in his saddle.

ən i wɑz mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf əɡɛn.

And he was muttering to himself again.

"ɹænd?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"Rand?" Nynaeve asked.

ɹænd stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪz bæk. hi wɑz ɹænd, wɑzn hi? səmtaɪmz, æftɝ ə bæɾəl laɪk ðɪs, hi hæd tʃɹʌbəl ɹɪkɔlɪŋ u hi wɑz. hæɾ i faɪnəli pʊʃt ɹænd, ði ɪntʃɹuɾɝ, ɪndə sɪkluʒən ən bɪkʌm luz θɝɪn? ðə pɹiviəs deɪ, hi hæd woʊkən ət mɪddeɪ, hʌɾəld ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz ɹumz, kɹaɪɪŋ ən wɪspɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf əbaʊɾ aɪlaɪɛnə. hi kəd fil ðə sɑf tɛkstʃɝ ə hɝ lɔŋ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ɪn ɪz hænz, ən kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ hoʊldɪŋ əɹ kloʊs. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ siɪŋ əɹ dɛɾ əɾ ɪz fit, sleɪn baɪ ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

Rand straightened his back. He was Rand, wasn't he? Sometimes, after a battle like this, he had trouble recalling who he was. Had he finally pushed Rand, the intruder, into seclusion and become Lews Therin? The previous day, he had woken at midday, huddled in the corner of his rooms, crying and whispering to himself about Ilyena. He could feel the soft texture of her long golden hair in his hands, and could remember holding her close. He could remember seeing her dead at his feet, slain by the One Power.

hu wɑz hi?

Who was he?

dɪɾ ɪt ɹɪli mæɾɝ?

Did it really matter?

"ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?" nɪneɪiv æskt əɡɛn.

"Are you all right?" Nynaeve asked again.

"wi ɑɹ faɪn." ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz hid juz ðə plʊɹəl əntɪl ðə wɝdz wɝ aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ.

"We are fine." Rand did not realize he'd used the plural until the words were out of his mouth.

hɪz vɪʒən wɑz ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪt stɪl sim dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl bɪt fʌzi. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz dɪstɔɹɾəd ə fɹækʃən, əz ɪt hæd bɪn sɪns ðə bæɾəl wɛɹ sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd teɪkən ɪz hænd. hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ɪɾ ɛnimɔɹ.

His vision was recovering, though it still seemed just a little bit fuzzy. Everything was distorted a fraction, as it had been since the battle where Semirhage had taken his hand. He barely noticed it anymore.

hi stʃɹeɪɾənd, ðən dʒɹu ə lɪɾəl ɛkstʃɹə paʊɝ θɹu ði æksɛs ki, fɪlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf wɪð seɪɾɪn.

He straightened, then drew a little extra power through the access key, filling himself with saidin.

ɪt wɑz soʊ swit, dɪspaɪt ðə nɔziə ðəɾ ɪt kɑzd. hi lɔŋ tə teɪk ɪn mɔɹ, bʌt hɛl hɪmsɛlf bæk.

It was so sweet, despite the nausea that it caused. He longed to take in more, but held himself back.

hi ɔlɹɛɾi hɛl mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ ðən ɛni mæn kəɾ əneɪɾɪd. ɪt wəd bi ɪnʌf.

He already held more of the Power than any man could unaided. It would be enough.

nɪneɪiv ɡlænst ət ðə fɪɡjɝin əɾ ɪz saɪd. ðə ɡloʊb ət ðə tɑp ɡloʊd feɪnli. "ɹænd. . . ."

Nynaeve glanced at the figurine at his side. The globe at the top glowed faintly. "Rand. . . ."

"aɪm oʊnli hoʊldɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ɛkstʃɹə, əz ə pɹikɔʃən." ðə mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ə pɝsən hɛld, ðə mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt ɪt wɑz tə ʃil ðɛm. ɪf ðə deɪmeɪn tʃɹaɪd tə kæptʃɝ hɪm, ðeɪ wəd bi ʃɑk baɪ hɪz ɹɪzɪliəns. hi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɹɪzɪst ə fʊl sɝkəl.

"I'm only holding a little extra, as a precaution." The more of the One Power a person held, the more difficult it was to shield them. If the damane tried to capture him, they would be shocked by his resilience. He might be able to resist a full circle.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt bi kæptʃɝɾ əɡɛn," hi wɪspɝd. "nɛvɝ əɡɛn. ðəl nɑt teɪk mi baɪ sɝpɹaɪz."

"I will not be captured again," he whispered. "Never again. They will not take me by surprise."

"meɪbi wi ʃəd tɝn bæk," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ɹænd, wi doʊn əv tə miɾ əm ɑn ðɛɹ tɝmz. ɪt  - "

"Maybe we should turn back," Nynaeve said. "Rand, we don't have to meet them on their terms. It  - "

"wi steɪ," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "wi dil wɪð əm hɪɹ ən naʊ." əhɛd, hi kəd si ə fɪɡjɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə pəvɪljən əɾ ə teɪbəl ɑn ə deɪz. ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃɛɹ əkɹɔs fɹəm ðə fɪɡjɝ, ɑn ən ikwəl lɛvəl.

"We stay," Rand said softly. "We deal with them here and now." Ahead, he could see a figure sitting in the pavilion at a table on a dais. There was a chair across from the figure, on an equal level.

ðət sɝpɹaɪz hɪm; fɹəm wʌɾ i nu ʌv ðə sintʃæn, hi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə hæv tə ɑɹɡju fəɹ ikwəl fʊɾɪŋ wɪð wʌn ə ðə blʌd.

That surprised him; from what he knew of the Seanchan, he had expected to have to argue for equal footing with one of the Blood.

wɑz ðɪs ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz? ðɪs tʃaɪld? ɹænd fɹaʊn əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt, bʌt ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑzn æktʃəli  ə tʃaɪld, dʒʌst ə vɛɹi smɔl wʊmən. dʒɹɛst ɪn blæk kloʊðɪŋ, ʃi hæd dɑɹk skɪn, laɪk wʌn ə ðə si foʊk. ðəɹ wɝ ɡɹeɪ-waɪɾ æʃəz ɑn ðə tʃiks ə hɝ kɑm, ɹaʊn feɪs. əpɑn kloʊs ɪnspɛkʃən, ʃi əpɪɹd tə bi nɪɹ ɪz oʊn eɪdʒ.

Was this the Daughter of the Nine Moons? This child? Rand frowned as they approached, but realized that she wasn't actually a child, just a very small woman. Dressed in black clothing, she had dark skin, like one of the Sea Folk. There were gray-white ashes on the cheeks of her calm, round face. Upon close inspection, she appeared to be near his own age.

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən dɪsmaʊntɪd. ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ðə wɔɹ tə ɛnd.

Rand took a deep breath and dismounted. It was time for the war to end.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ə jʌŋ mæn. tuɑn hæd bɪn toʊl ðæt, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt stɪl sɝpɹaɪz hɝ.

The Dragon Reborn was a young man. Tuon had been told that, but something about it still surprised her.

waɪ ʃəd ʃi bi sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ðɪs juθ? kɑŋkɝɪŋ hɪɹoʊz wɝ ɔfən jʌŋ. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, ði ɛmpaɪɝz ɡɹeɪt pɹoʊdʒɛnɪɾɝ, hæd bɪn ə jʌŋ mæn wən hid bɪɡʌn ɪz kɑŋkwɛst.

Why should she be surprised by this youth? Conquering heroes were often young. Artur Hawkwing himself, the Empire's great progenitor, had been a young man when he'd begun his conquest.

ðoʊz u kɑŋkɝd, ðoʊz u dɑməneɪɾəd ðə wɝld, bɝn ðɛmsɛlvz aʊt kwɪkli, laɪk læmps wɪð əntʃɹɪmd wɪks. hi wɔɹ ɡoʊld ən ɹɛɾ ɑn blæk, ðə bʌɾənz ɑn ɪz koʊt spɑɹklɪŋ əz i dɪsmaʊntɪd fɹəm ɪz lɑɹdʒ blæk ɡɛldɪŋ ən əpɹoʊtʃt ðə pəvɪljən. ðə blæk koʊt hæd ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ðə kʌfs - ðə mɪsɪŋ hænd wɑz kwaɪɾ ɑbviəs, lʊkɪŋ ət ðoʊz kʌfs - bʌɾ ɪz kloʊðɪŋ wɑz ʌðɝwaɪz ʌnədɔɹnd. əz ɪf i sɔ noʊ nid tə dɪstʃɹæk fɹəm ɪz feɪs wɪð faɪnɝi.

Those who conquered, those who dominated the world, burned themselves out quickly, like lamps with untrimmed wicks. He wore gold and red on black, the buttons on his coat sparkling as he dismounted from his large black gelding and approached the pavilion. The black coat had red and gold embroidery on the cuffs - the missing hand was quite obvious, looking at those cuffs - but his clothing was otherwise unadorned. As if he saw no need to distract from his face with finery.

hɪz hɛɹ wɑz ðə kʌlɝ ʌv ə dip sʌnsɛt, ə dɑɹk ɹɛd. hi hæɾ ə ɹiɡəl bɛɹɪŋ tə hɪm - ə stʃɹaɪd ðət wɑz fɝm, itʃ stɛp kɑnfəɾənt, aɪz stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. tuɑn hæd bɪn tʃɹeɪn tə wɔk ðət weɪ, tə ɡɪv noʊ kɔɹɾɝ, ɪn ðə weɪ ʃi stɛpt. hu hæd tʃɹeɪn hɪm, ʃi wʌndɝd. laɪkli, hi hæd ðə faɪnəst ə titʃɝz tə pɹipɛɹ ɪm ɪn ðə weɪz ə kɪŋz ən liɾɝz. jɛt ɹɪpɔɹts sɛɾ i hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp əz ə fɑɹmɝ ɪn ə ɹʊɹəl vɪlədʒ. ə stɔɹi, kɛɹfəli spɹɛd tə bɹɪŋ ɪm kɹɛɾəbɪlɪti wɪð ðə kɑmən pipəl, pɝhæps?

His hair was the color of a deep sunset, a dark red. He had a regal bearing to him - a stride that was firm, each step confident, eyes straight ahead. Tuon had been trained to walk that way, to give no quarter, in the way she stepped. Who had trained him, she wondered. Likely, he had the finest of teachers to prepare him in the ways of kings and leaders. Yet reports said he had grown up as a farmer in a rural village. A story, carefully spread to bring him credibility with the common people, perhaps?

hi stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ðə pəvɪljən, ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɑn ɪz lɛft. ðə wʊmən wɔɹ ə dʒɹɛs kʌlɝd laɪk ðə skaɪ ɑn ə klɪɹ deɪ, sɛt wɪð tʃɹɪm laɪk klaʊdz. ʃi wɔɹ əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl dɑɹk bɹeɪɾ ən ədɔɹn hɝsɛlf wɪð ə sɛɾ ʌv ɡɔɾi dʒuəlɹi. ʃi sim dɪspliz baɪ sʌmθɪŋ, hɝ bɹaʊ fɝoʊd, hɝ maʊð ə taɪt laɪn. hɝ pɹɛzəns meɪd tuɑn ʃɪvɝ. wʌn wəd θɪŋk ʃiɾ əv ɡɹoʊn mɔɹ əkʌstəm tə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, æftɝ tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð meɪtʃɹim. bʌt nɑt soʊ. ðeɪ wɝ ənnætʃɹəl.

He strode up to the pavilion, a marath'damane on his left. The woman wore a dress colored like the sky on a clear day, set with trim like clouds. She wore her hair in a single dark braid and adorned herself with a set of gaudy jewelry. She seemed displeased by something, her brow furrowed, her mouth a tight line. Her presence made Tuon shiver. One would think she'd have grown more accustomed to marath'damane, after traveling with Matrim. But not so. They were unnatural.

deɪnʒɝəs. tuɑn kəd noʊ mɔɹ ɡɹoʊ kʌmftəɹbəl ɝaʊn ən ənliʃt deɪmeɪn ðən ʃi kəd tɑlɝeɪt hævɪŋ ə ɡɹæsfæŋ twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn əɹ æŋkəl, ɪts tʌŋ tɪklɪŋ əɹ skɪn.

Dangerous. Tuon could no more grow comfortable around an unleashed damane than she could tolerate having a grassfang twisted around her ankle, its tongue tickling her skin.

ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn wɑz ənsɛɾəlɪŋ, ðən ðə tu mɛn u wɔk tə ðə ɹaɪɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən wɝ mɔɹ soʊ. wʌn, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə juθ, wɔɹ ɪz hɛɹ ɪn bɹeɪdz taɪd wɪð bɛlz. ði ʌðɝ wɑz ən oʊldɝ mæn wɪð waɪt hɛɹ ən ə tæn feɪs. dɪspaɪt ðə dɪfɝəns ɪn ðɛɹ eɪdʒəz, boʊθ wɔkt wɪð ðə kæʒəwəl swæɡɝ ə mɛn wɛl əkweɪntəd wɪð bæɾəl. ən boʊθ wɔɹ blæk koʊts, spɑɹklɪŋ pɪnz ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝz. æʃəmən, ðeɪ wɝ kɔld. mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. əbɑməneɪʃənz bɛs kɪl kwɪkli. ɪn sintʃæn, ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə vɛɹi fju hu - ɪn ðɛɹ lʌs fəɹ ən ʌnæntɪsəpeɪɾɪd ɛdʒ -  hæd tʃɹaɪd tə tʃɹeɪn ðiz tsɹoʊvæn dun, ðiz blæk-soʊl tɛmpɛsts. ðə fulz hæd fɔlən kwɪkli, ɔfən dɪstʃɹɔɪd baɪ ðə vɛɹi tulz ðət ðeɪ sɔt tə kəntʃɹoʊl.

Of course, if the marath'damane was unsettling, then the two men who walked to the right of the Dragon were more so. One, little more than a youth, wore his hair in braids tied with bells. The other was an older man with white hair and a tanned face. Despite the difference in their ages, both walked with the casual swagger of men well acquainted with battle. And both wore black coats, sparkling pins on the high collars. Asha'man, they were called. Men who could channel. Abominations best killed quickly. In Seanchan, there had been a very few who - in their lust for an unanticipated edge -  had tried to train these Tsorov'ande Doon, these Black-Souled Tempests. The fools had fallen quickly, often destroyed by the very tools that they sought to control.

tuɑn stil hɝsɛlf. kɛɹiɾ ən ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz ɝaʊn əɹ ɡɹu tɛns. ɪt wɑz sʌɾəl -  fɪsts taɪɾənɪŋ ət ðɛɹ saɪdz, bɹɛθs ɪnheɪld ən ɹilist sloʊli. tuɑn dɪdn tɝn təwɔɹd ðɛm, ðoʊ ʃi meɪɾ ə koʊvɝt dʒɛstʃɝ tə sɪlutʃə.

Tuon steeled herself. Karede and the Deathwatch Guards around her grew tense. It was subtle -  fists tightening at their sides, breaths inhaled and released slowly. Tuon didn't turn toward them, though she made a covert gesture to Selucia.

"ju ɑɹ tə meɪnteɪn jəɹ kɑm," ðə vɔɪs sɛd sɔfli tə ðə mɛn.

"You are to maintain your calm," the Voice said softly to the men.

ðeɪ wəd də soʊ - ðeɪ wɝ dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd. tuɑn heɪɾəd tə meɪk ðə kɑmɛnt, əz ɪt wəd loʊɝ ðɛɹ aɪz. bʌt ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ə mɪshæp. miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wəd bi deɪnʒɝəs. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðæt. ivən wɪð twɛnti deɪmeɪn ən sʌldəm ɑn itʃ saɪɾ ə ðə pəvɪljən. ivən wɪð kɛɹiɾ əɾ əɹ bæk ən kæptən mjuzənʒ ən ə fɔɹs ʌv ɑɹtʃɝz wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm ə kʌvɝd ɹuftɑp dʒʌst wɪðɪn baʊʃɑt. ivən wɪð sɪlutʃə əɾ əɹ ɹaɪt, tɛns ən ɹɛɾi tə paʊns, laɪk ə dʒæɡwɪn ɑn ðə haɪ ɹɑks. ivən wɪð ɔl ə ðæt, tuɑn wɑz ɪkspoʊzd. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ə bɑnfaɪɝ ɪnɪksplɪkəbli lɪɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ə haʊs. jə kəd nɑt pɹɪvɛn ɪt fɹəm dæmɪdʒɪŋ ðə ɹum. jə dʒʌs hoʊp tə seɪv ðə bɪldɪŋ.

They would do so - they were Deathwatch Guard. Tuon hated to make the comment, as it would lower their eyes. But she would not have a mishap. Meeting with the Dragon Reborn would be dangerous. There was no avoiding that. Even with twenty damane and sul'dam on each side of the pavilion. Even with Karede at her back and Captain Musenge and a force of archers watching from a covered rooftop just within bowshot. Even with Selucia at her right, tense and ready to pounce, like a jagwin on the high rocks. Even with all of that, Tuon was exposed. The Dragon Reborn was a bonfire inexplicably lit inside a house. You could not prevent it from damaging the room. You just hoped to save the building.

hi wɔk dɝɛkli tə ðə tʃɛɹ ɑpəzət tuɑn ən sæt daʊn, nɛvɝ wʌns kwɛstʃənɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd sɛɾ ɪm əz əɹ ikwəl. ʃi nu ðət ði ʌðɝz wʌndɝd waɪ ʃi stɪl wɔɹ ði æʃəz ə mɔɹnɪŋ, waɪ ʃi hædn pɹoʊkleɪm hɝsɛlf ɛmpɹɛs. ðə mɔɹnɪŋ pɪɹiəd wɑz oʊvɝ, bʌt tuɑn hæd nɑt teɪkən əɹ θɹoʊn.

He walked directly to the chair opposite Tuon and sat down, never once questioning that she had set him as her equal. She knew that the others wondered why she still wore the ashes of mourning, why she hadn't proclaimed herself Empress. The mourning period was over, but Tuon had not taken her throne.

ɪt wɑz kəz ə ðɪs mæn. ði ɛmpɹɛs kəd nɑt miɾ ɛniwʌn, nɑɾ ivən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, əz ən ikwəl. ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz, haʊɛvɝ . . . ðɪs wʌn mæn kəd bi hɝ ikwəl. ən soʊ ʃi hæd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wəd nɑt laɪkli ɹɪspɑnd wɛl tə ənʌðɝ sɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf əbʌv hɪm, noʊ mæɾɝ ɪf ðəɾ ʌðɝ hæɾ ə pɝfəkli lədʒɪɾəmət ɹizən fəɹ duɪŋ soʊ.

It was because of this man. The Empress could not meet anyone, not even the Dragon Reborn, as an equal. The Daughter of the Nine Moons, however . . . this one man could be her equal. And so she had hesitated. The Dragon Reborn would not likely respond well to another setting herself above him, no matter if that other had a perfectly legitimate reason for doing so.

əz i sæt daʊn, ə dɪstən flɛɹ ə laɪtnɪŋ ɑɹs bɪtwin tu klaʊdz, ðoʊ məlɑi - wʌn ə ðə deɪmeɪn u kəd tɛl fɔɹtʃənz ə ðə wɛðɝ - hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd ðət noʊ ɹeɪn wɑz nɪɹ. laɪtnɪŋ ɑn ə deɪ wɪθaʊt ɹeɪn. tʃɹɛd vɛɹi laɪtli, ʃi θɔt, ɹiɾɪŋ ði oʊmən, ən bi kɛɹfəl wʌt jə spik.

As he sat down, a distant flare of lightning arced between two clouds, though Malai - one of the damane who could tell fortunes of the weather - had insisted that no rain was near. Lightning on a day without rain. Tread very lightly, she thought, reading the omen, and be careful what you speak.

nɑt ðə moʊst ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ʌv oʊmənz. ɪf ʃi tʃɹɑɾ ɛni mɔɹ kɛɹfəli, ʃi wəɾ əv tə teɪk flaɪɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ!

Not the most illuminating of omens. If she trod any more carefully, she would have to take flight into the air!

"ju ɑɹ ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz," ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn sɛd. ɪt wɑz ə steɪtmənt, nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən.

"You are the Daughter of the Nine Moons," the Dragon Reborn said. It was a statement, not a question.

"ju ɑɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðoʊz sleɪtlaɪk aɪz, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ ɪn əɹ fɝst ɪmpɹɛʃən. hi wɑz nɑɾ ə jʌŋ mæn. jɛs, hɪz bɑɾi maɪt bi ðəɾ ʌv ə juθ. bʌt ðoʊz aɪz . . . ðoʊz wɝ oʊld aɪz.

"You are the Dragon Reborn," she replied. Looking into those slatelike eyes, she realized that she had been wrong in her first impression. He was not a young man. Yes, his body might be that of a youth. But those eyes . . . those were old eyes.

hi lin fɔɹwɝd slaɪtli. hɝ dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz tɛnst, lɛðɝ kɹikɪŋ. "wi wɪl meɪk pis," ælθɹ sɛd. "tədeɪ. hɪɹ."

He leaned forward slightly. Her Deathwatch Guards tensed, leather creaking. "We will make peace," al'Thor said. "Today. Here."

sɪlutʃə hɪst sɔfli. hɪz wɝdz saʊndəɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil laɪk ə dɪmænd. tuɑn hæd ʃoʊn ɪm ɡɹeɪt ɹɪspɛk baɪ pleɪsɪŋ ɪm əɾ əɹ lɛvəl, bʌt wʌn dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ɔɹɾɝz tə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli.

Selucia hissed softly. His words sounded a great deal like a demand. Tuon had shown him great respect by placing him at her level, but one did not give orders to the Imperial family.

ælθɹ ɡlænst ət sɪlutʃə. "ju kən tɛl jəɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹd ðət ʃi kən ɹɪlæks," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ðɪs miɾɪŋ wɪl nɑt tɝn tə kənflɪkt. əl nɑɾ əlaʊ ɪt."

Al'Thor glanced at Selucia. "You can tell your bodyguard that she can relax," he said dryly. "This meeting will not turn to conflict. I will not allow it."

"ʃi ɪz maɪ vɔɪs," tuɑn sɛd kɛɹfəli, "æn maɪ tʃɹuθspikɝ. maɪ bɑɾiɡɑɹd ɪz ðə mæn bɪhaɪn maɪ tʃɛɹ."

"She is my Voice," Tuon said carefully, "and my Truthspeaker. My bodyguard is the man behind my chair."

ælθɹ snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli. soʊ hi wɑz ən əbzɝvən mæn. əɹ ə lʌki wʌn. fju hæd kɝɛkli ɡɛst sɪlutʃəz neɪtʃɝ.

Al'Thor snorted softly. So he was an observant man. Or a lucky one. Few had correctly guessed Selucia's nature.

"ju wɪʃ fəɹ pis," tuɑn sɛd. "hæv jə tɝmz fəɹ jəɹ . . . ɔfɝ?"

"You wish for peace," Tuon said. "Have you terms for your . . . offer?"

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑɾ ən ɔfɝ, bʌɾ ə nəsɛsəɾi," ælθɹ sɛd. hi spoʊk wɪð sɔfnəs. ɔl ə ðiz pipəl spoʊk wɪð sətʃ kwɪk wɝdz, jɛɾ ælθɹz hæɾ ə weɪt tə ðɛm. hi ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ ə hɝ mʌðɝ.

"It is not an offer, but a necessity," al'Thor said. He spoke with softness. All of these people spoke with such quick words, yet al'Thor's had a weight to them. He reminded her of her mother.

"ðə læs bæɾəl kʌmz. ʃʊɹli jəɹ pipəl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə pɹɑfəsiz. baɪ pɹɑsɪkjuɾɪŋ ðɪs wɔɹ ə jʊɹz, jə ɛndeɪnʒɝ əs ɔl. maɪ fɔɹsɪz -  ɛvɹiwʌnz fɔɹsɪz  - ɑɹ niɾəd ɪn ðə stʃɹʌɡəl əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ."

"The Last Battle comes. Surely your people remember the prophecies. By prosecuting this war of yours, you endanger us all. My forces -  everyone's forces  - are needed in the struggle against the Shadow."

ðə læs bæɾəl wəd bi bɪtwin ði ɛmpaɪɝ ən ðə fɔɹsɪz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɛvɹibɑɾi nu ðæt. ðə pɹɑfəsiz klɪɹli ʃoʊd ðət ði ɛmpɹɛs wəd dɪfit ðoʊz u sɝv ðə ʃædoʊ, ən ðən ʃi wəd sɛn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn tə duəl wɪð laɪtiɾɝ.

The Last Battle would be between the Empire and the forces of the Dark One. Everybody knew that. The prophecies clearly showed that the Empress would defeat those who served the Shadow, and then she would send the Dragon Reborn in to duel with Lighteater.

haʊ mʌtʃ hæɾ i fʊlfɪld? hi dɪdn sim blaɪndɪd jɛt, soʊ ðət hæd jɛt tə hæpən. ði ɛsænɪk saɪkəl sɛd ðəɾ i wəd stæn ɑn ɪz oʊn ɡɹeɪv ən wip. əɹ dɪd ðət pɹɑfəsi ɹəfɝ tə ðə dɛd wɔkɪŋ, əz ðeɪ dɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi? sɝɾənli, səm ə ðoʊz spɪɹəts hæd wɔkt əkɹɔs ðɛɹ oʊn ɡɹeɪvz.

How much had he fulfilled? He didn't seem blinded yet, so that had yet to happen. The Essanik Cycle said that he would stand on his own grave and weep. Or did that prophecy refer to the dead walking, as they did already? Certainly, some of those spirits had walked across their own graves.

ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋz wɝ ənklɪɹ, səmtaɪmz.

The writings were unclear, sometimes.

ðɪs pipəl sim tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən mɛni ʌv ðə pɹɑfəsiz, dʒʌst əz ðeɪ fɝɡɑt ðɛɹ oʊðz tə wɑtʃ fəɹ ðə ɹɪtɝn. bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt seɪ ðɪs. wɑtʃ jəɹ wɝdz kɛɹfəli. . . .

This people seemed to have forgotten many of the prophecies, just as they forgot their oaths to watch for the Return. But she did not say this. Watch your words carefully. . . .

"ju bɪliv ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz kloʊs, ðɛn?" ʃi æskt.

"You believe the Last Battle is close, then?" she asked.

"kloʊs?" ælθɹ æskt. "ɪɾ ɪz əz kloʊz əz ən əsæsən, bɹiðɪŋ ɪz faʊl bɹɛθ əpɑn jəɹ nɛk əz i slaɪdz ɪz naɪf əkɹɔs jəɹ skɪn. ɪts kloʊs laɪk ðə læs tʃaɪm ə mɪdnaɪt, æftɝ ði ʌðɝ ɪlɛvən əv stʃɹʌk. kloʊs? jɛs, ɪts kloʊs. hɔɹəbli kloʊs."

"Close?" al'Thor asked. "It is as close as an assassin, breathing his foul breath upon your neck as he slides his knife across your skin. It is close like the last chime of midnight, after the other eleven have struck. Close? Yes, it is close. Horribly close."

hæd ðə mædnəs teɪkən ɪm ɔlɹɛɾi? ɪf ɪt hæd, ðət wəd meɪk θɪŋz mʌtʃ mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt. ʃi stʌɾid hɪm, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ saɪnz ʌv ɪnsænəɾi. hi simd ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɪmsɛlf.

Had the madness taken him already? If it had, that would make things much more difficult. She studied him, searching for signs of insanity. He seemed in control of himself.

ə si bɹiz blu θɹu ðə kænəpi, ɹʌfəlɪŋ ðə kænvəs ən kæɹiɪŋ wɪð ɪt ðə sɛn ə ɹɑɾən fɪʃ. mɛni θɪŋz sim tə bi ɹɑɾɪŋ ðiz deɪz.

A sea breeze blew through the canopy, ruffling the canvas and carrying with it the scent of rotten fish. Many things seemed to be rotting these days.

ðoʊz kɹitʃɝz, ʃi θɔt. ðə tʃɹɑləks. wʌd ðɛɹ əpɪɹəns fɔɹtɛl? taɪli hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðɛm, ən ðə skaʊts hæd faʊnd noʊ ʌðɝz. lʊkɪŋ ət ði ɪntɛnsəɾi ʌv ðɪs mæn, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

Those creatures, she thought. The Trollocs. What did their appearance foretell? Tylee had destroyed them, and the scouts had found no others. Looking at the intensity of this man, she hesitated.

jɛs, ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz kloʊs, pɝhæps əz kloʊs əz i sɛd. ðət meɪɾ ɪɾ ɔl ðə mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðət ʃi junəfaɪ ðiz lænz bɪniθ əɹ bænɝ.

Yes, the Last Battle was close, perhaps as close as he said. That made it all the more important that she unify these lands beneath her banner.

"ju mʌst si waɪ ðɪs ɪz soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt," ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn sɛd. "waɪ dʒju faɪt mi?"

"You must see why this is so important," the Dragon Reborn said. "Why do you fight me?"

"wi ɑɹ ðə ɹɪtɝn," tuɑn sɛd. "ði oʊmənz sɛɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ əs tə kʌm, ən wi ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn ə junaɪɾəd kɪŋdəm, ɹɛɾi tə pɹeɪz əs ən lɛn əs ɑɹmiz fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. ɪnstɛd, wi faʊn ə fɹæktʃɝd læn ðət hæd fɝɡɑɾən ɪts oʊðz ən pɹipɛɹd fəɹ nʌθɪŋ. haʊ kən jə nɑt si ðət wi mʌs faɪt? ɪt dʌz nɑt bɹɪŋ əs plɛʒɝ tə kɪl ju, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɪt bɹɪŋz ə pɛɹən dʒɔɪ tə dɪsəplən ə tʃaɪld u hæz ɡɔn əstʃɹeɪ."

"We are the Return," Tuon said. "The omens said it was time for us to come, and we expected to find a united kingdom, ready to praise us and lend us armies for the Last Battle. Instead, we found a fractured land that had forgotten its oaths and prepared for nothing. How can you not see that we must fight? It does not bring us pleasure to kill you, no more than it brings a parent joy to discipline a child who has gone astray."

ælθɹ simd ɪnkɹɛdʒələs. "wi ɑɹ tʃɪlʒɹən tə ju?"

Al'Thor seemed incredulous. "We are children to you?"

"ɪt wɑz ə mɛɾəfɔɹ oʊnli," tuɑn sɛd.

"It was a metaphor only," Tuon said.

hi sæt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn wɪð ɪz hænd. dɪɾ i bleɪm əɹ fəɹ ðə lɔs ə ði ʌðɝ wʌn? fælɛnʒɹ hæd spoʊkən ʌv ɪt.

He sat for a moment, then rubbed his chin with his hand. Did he blame her for the loss of the other one? Falendre had spoken of it.

"ə mɛɾəfɔɹ," hi sɛd. "æn æpt wʌn, pɝhæps. jɛs, ðə læn dɪd læk junəɾi. bʌɾ aɪ hæv fɔɹdʒd ɪt təɡɛðɝ. ðə sɑɾɝ ɪz wik, pɝhæps, bʌɾ ɪɾəl hoʊld lɔŋ ɪnʌf. ɪf nɑt fəɹ mi, ðən jəɹ wɔɹ ə junəfəkeɪʃən wəd bi kəmɛndəbəl. əz ɪɾ ɪz, jə ɑɹ ə dɪstʃɹækʃən. wi mʌst əv pis. əɹ əlaɪəns nid læst oʊnli əntɪl maɪ laɪf ɛnz." hi mɛɾ əɹ aɪz. "aɪ əʃʊɹ jə ðət wɪl nɑt bi oʊvɝli lɔŋ."

"A metaphor," he said. "An apt one, perhaps. Yes, the land did lack unity. But I have forged it together. The solder is weak, perhaps, but it will hold long enough. If not for me, then your war of unification would be commendable. As it is, you are a distraction. We must have peace. Our alliance need last only until my life ends." He met her eyes. "I assure you that will not be overly long."

ʃi sæɾ ət ðə waɪd teɪbəl, ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪfɔɹ hɝ. ɪf ælθɹ stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɪz ɑɹm, hi wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə ɹitʃ hɝ. ðət wɑz ɪntɛnʃənəl, ðoʊ ðə pɹikɔʃən wɑz læfəbəl, ɪn haɪndsaɪt. hi wəd nɑt niɾ ɪz hænd ʃəɾ i dɪsaɪd tə kɪl hɝ. bɛs nɑt tə θɪŋk ə ðæt.

She sat at the wide table, arms folded before her. If al'Thor stretched out his arm, he would not be able to reach her. That was intentional, though the precaution was laughable, in hindsight. He would not need his hand should he decide to kill her. Best not to think of that.

"ɪf jə si ðə vælju ʌv junəfəkeɪʃən," ʃi sɛd, "ðɛn pɝhæps jə ʃəd junaɪt jəɹ lænz bɪniθ ðə sintʃæn bænɝ, hæv jəɹ pipəl teɪk ði oʊðz ən - " ðə wʊmən stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn ælθɹ, ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, oʊpən aɪz waɪɾ əz tuɑn spoʊk.

"If you see the value of unification," she said, "then perhaps you should unite your lands beneath the Seanchan banner, have your people take the oaths and - " The woman standing behind al'Thor, the marath'damane, opened eyes wide as Tuon spoke.

"noʊ," ælθɹ sɛd, ɪntɝʌptɪŋ tuɑn.

"No," al'Thor said, interrupting Tuon.

"bʌt ʃʊɹli jə kən si ðət wʌn ɹulɝ, wɪð - "

"But surely you can see that one ruler, with - "

"noʊ," hi sɛd, sɔfli, jɛt mɔɹ fɝmli. mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs. "aɪ wɪl nɑt si ənʌðɝ pɝsən tʃeɪn baɪ jəɹ faʊl liʃɪz."

"No," he said, softly, yet more firmly. More dangerous. "I will not see another person chained by your foul leashes."

"faʊl? ðeɪ ɑɹ ði oʊnli weɪ tə dil wɪð ðoʊz u kən tʃænəl!"

"Foul? They are the only way to deal with those who can channel!"

"wi hæv sɝvaɪvd wɪθaʊɾ əm fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz."

"We have survived without them for centuries."

"æn juv - "

"And you have - "

"ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə pɔɪn əl kənsid," ælθɹ sɛd.

"This is not a point I will concede," al'Thor said.

tuɑnz ɡɑɹdz - sɪlutʃə ɪnkluɾəd - ɡɹɪɾɪd ðɛɹ tiθ, ən ðə ɡɑɹdz dʒɹɑp hænz tə sɔɹd hɪls. hi hæɾ ɪntɝʌptɪɾ əɹ twaɪs ɪn ə ɹoʊ. ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. haʊ kəɾ i bi soʊ boʊld?

Tuon's guards - Selucia included - gritted their teeth, and the guards dropped hands to sword hilts. He had interrupted her twice in a row. The Daughter of the Nine Moons. How could he be so bold?

hi wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðət wɑz haʊ. bʌɾ ɪz wɝdz wɝ fulɪʃnəs. hi wəd baʊ bɪfɔɹ hɝ, wʌns ʃi wɑz ɛmpɹɛs. ðə pɹɑfəsiz dɪmændəɾ ɪt. ʃʊɹli ðət mɛn ðəɾ ɪz kɪŋdəmz wəd dʒɔɪn wɪð ði ɛmpaɪɝ.

He was the Dragon Reborn, that was how. But his words were foolishness. He would bow before her, once she was Empress. The prophecies demanded it. Surely that meant that his kingdoms would join with the Empire.

ʃi hæd lɛt ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən slɪp aʊɾ ə hɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn wɝ ə tʌtʃi sʌbʒɪkt tə mɛni ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən. ðeɪ laɪkli ʌndɝstʊd ðə lɑdʒɪk ɪn liʃɪŋ ðə wɪmən, bʌt ðɛɹ tʃɹədɪʃənz wɝ dɪfəkəl tə ɹɪlɪŋkwɪʃ. ðət wɑz noʊ daʊt waɪ ðeɪ wɝ soʊ dɪstɝbd baɪ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðiz θɪŋz.

She had let the conversation slip out of her control. The marath'damane were a touchy subject to many on this side of the ocean. They likely understood the logic in leashing the women, but their traditions were difficult to relinquish. That was no doubt why they were so disturbed by talking about these things.

ʃi niɾəd tə nʌdʒ ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɪn ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃənz. ɪndə ə ɹɛlm ðət wəd θɹoʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɔf ɡɑɹd. ʃi stʌɾid hɪm. "ɪz ðɪs ɔl əɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɪz tə bi əbaʊt?" ʃi sɛd.

She needed to nudge the conversation in other directions. Into a realm that would throw the Dragon Reborn off guard. She studied him. "Is this all our conversation is to be about?" she said.

"wi sɪɾ əkɹɔs fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝ ən spik oʊnli ʌv əɹ dɪfɝənsɪz?"

"We sit across from one another and speak only of our differences?"

"wʌɾ ɛls wəd wi tɔk əbaʊt?" ælθɹ sɛd.

"What else would we talk about?" al'Thor said.

"pɝhæps sʌmθɪŋ wɪv ɪn kɑmən."

"Perhaps something we have in common."

"aɪ daʊt ðəɹ ɪz mʌtʃ ɪn ðəɾ ɛɹiə ðəɾ ɪz ɹɛləvənt."

"I doubt there is much in that area that is relevant."

"oʊ?" tuɑn sɛd. "ænd wʌɾ ə meɪtʃɹim kɔθən?"

"Oh?" Tuon said. "And what of Matrim Cauthon?"

jɛs, ðət ʃɑk hɪm. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn blɪŋkt, maʊθ oʊpənɪŋ slaɪtli. "mæt?" hi sɛd.

Yes, that shocked him. The Dragon Reborn blinked, mouth opening slightly. "Mat?" he said.

"ju noʊ mæt? haʊ . . ."

"You know Mat? How . . ."

"hi kɪdnæp mi," tuɑn sɛd. "æn dʒɹæɡd mi moʊst ə ðə weɪ əkɹɔs ɔltɑɹə."

"He kidnapped me," Tuon said. "And dragged me most of the way across Altara."

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɡeɪpt, ðən ʃʌɾ ɪz maʊθ. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ naʊ," hi sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ sɔ ju.

The Dragon Reborn gaped, then shut his mouth. "I remember now," he said softly. "I saw you.

wɪð hɪm. aɪ dɪd nɑt kənɛk jə tə ðət feɪs. mæt . . . wʌɾ əv jə bɪn duɪŋ?"

With him. I did not connect you to that face. Mat . . . what have you been doing?"

jə sɔ ʌs? tuɑn θɔt skɛptɪkəli. soʊ ðə mædnəs hæd mænəfɛstəɾ ɪtsɛlf. wəd ðət meɪk ɪm iziɝ tə mənɪpjəleɪt, əɹ mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt? pɹɑbli ðə læɾɝ, ənfɔɹtʃənətli.

You saw us? Tuon thought skeptically. So the madness had manifested itself. Would that make him easier to manipulate, or more difficult? Probably the latter, unfortunately.

"wɛl," ælθɹ faɪnəli sɛd, "aɪ tʃɹʌs ðət mæt hæɾ ɪz ɹizənz. hi ɔlweɪz dʌz. ən ðeɪ sim soʊ lɑdʒɪkəl tə hɪm ət ðə taɪm. . . ."

"Well," al'Thor finally said, "I trust that Mat had his reasons. He always does. And they seem so logical to him at the time. . . ."

soʊ, meɪtʃɹim dɪd noʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn; hi wəd bi ən ɛksələn ɹisɔɹs tə hɝ. pɝhæps ðət wɑz waɪ hi hæd bɪn bɹɔt tə hɝ, soʊ ʃi wəɾ əv ə minz ə lɝnɪŋ əbaʊt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

So, Matrim did know the Dragon Reborn; he would be an excellent resource to her. Perhaps that was why he had been brought to her, so she would have a means of learning about the Dragon Reborn.

ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ɪm bɪfɔɹ i kəd hɛlp əɹ ɪn ðəɾ ɛɹiə.

She would have to recover him before he could help her in that area.

meɪtʃɹim wəd nɑt laɪk ðæt, bʌɾ i wəɾ əv tə si ɹizən. hi wɑz fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz.

Matrim would not like that, but he would have to see reason. He was First Prince of the Ravens.

hi niɾəd tə bi ɹeɪz tə ðə haɪ blʌd, ʃeɪv ɪz hɛɾ ən lɝn ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪ ʌv lɪvɪŋ. ðəɾ ɔl simd ə ʃeɪm tə hɝ - fəɹ ɹizənz ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn tə hɝsɛlf.

He needed to be raised to the High Blood, shave his head and learn the proper way of living. That all seemed a shame to her - for reasons she could not explain to herself.

ʃi kʊdn hɛlp æskɪŋ æftɝ ɪm ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ. pɑɹtli kəz ðə tɑpɪk əpɪɹd tə ənbæləns ælθɹ, ən pɑɹtli kəz ʃi wɑz kjʊɹiəs. "wʌt taɪp ə mæn ɪz hi, ðɪs meɪtʃɹim kɔθən? aɪ mʌst ədmɪt, aɪ faʊn ɪm tə bi sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ən ɪndələn skaʊnʒɹəl, tu kwɪk tə faɪn ɪkskjusɪz tə əvɔɪɾ oʊðz hid teɪkən."

She couldn't help asking after him a little more. Partly because the topic appeared to unbalance al'Thor, and partly because she was curious. "What type of man is he, this Matrim Cauthon? I must admit, I found him to be something of an indolent scoundrel, too quick to find excuses to avoid oaths he'd taken."

"doʊn spik ə hɪm ðət weɪ!" sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðə wɝdz keɪm fɹəm ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ælθɹz tʃɛɹ.

"Don't speak of him that way!" Surprisingly, the words came from the marath'damane standing beside al'Thor's chair.

"nɪneɪiv . . ." ælθɹ bɪɡæn.

"Nynaeve . . ." al'Thor began.

"doʊn hʌʃ mi, ɹænd ælθɹ," ðə wʊmən sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "hiz jəɹ fɹɛn tu." ðə wʊmən lʊk bæk ət tuɑn, miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz. miɾɪŋ ðɛm. ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn!

"Don't hush me, Rand al'Thor," the woman said, folding her arms. "He's your friend too." The woman looked back at Tuon, meeting her eyes. Meeting them. A marath'damane!

ʃi kəntɪnjud, "meɪtʃɹim kɔθən ɪz wʌn ə ðə faɪnəs mɛn jəl ɛvɝ noʊ, jəɹ haɪnəs, ən aɪ woʊn lɪsən tə ɪl spitʃ ə hɪm. wʌts ɹaɪɾ ɪz ɹaɪt."

She continued, "Matrim Cauthon is one of the finest men you will ever know, Your Highness, and I won't listen to ill speech of him. What's right is right."

"nɪneɪiv ɪz ɹaɪt," ælθɹ sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "hi ɪz ə ɡʊd mæn. mæt meɪ sim ə lɪɾəl ɹʌf ət taɪmz, bʌt hiz əz sɑləɾ ə fɹɛn əz wʌn kəd hoʊp fɔɹ. ðoʊ hi dʌz ɡɹʌmbəl əbaʊt wʌɾ ɪz kɑnʃəns meɪks ɪm du."

"Nynaeve is right," al'Thor said reluctantly. "He is a good man. Mat may seem a little rough at times, but he is as solid a friend as one could hope for. Though he does grumble about what his conscience makes him do."

"hi seɪv maɪ laɪf," ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn sɛd. "ɹɛskjud mi ət ɡɹeɪt kɑst ən pɝsənəl deɪnʒɝ wən noʊ ʌðɝ θɔt tə kʌm fəɹ mi." hɝ aɪz wɝ əfaɪɹ wɪð æŋɡɝ. "jɛs, hi dʒɹɪŋks ən ɡæmbəlz fɑɹ tu mʌtʃ. bʌt doʊn spik ə hɪm əz ɪf jə noʊ hɪm, kəz jə doʊnt. hɪz hɑɹɾ ɪz ɡoʊldən, ʌndɝ ɪɾ ɔl. ɪf juv hɝt hɪm. . . ."

"He saved my life," the marath'damane said. "Rescued me at great cost and personal danger when no other thought to come for me." Her eyes were afire with anger. "Yes, he drinks and gambles far too much. But don't speak of him as if you know him, because you don't. His heart is golden, under it all. If you've hurt him. . . ."

"hɝt hɪm?" tuɑn sɛd. "hi kɪdnæp mi!"

"Hurt him?" Tuon said. "He kidnapped me!"

"ɪf i dɪd soʊ, ðən ðəɹ wɑz kɑz," ɹænd ælθɹ sɛd.

"If he did so, then there was cause," Rand al'Thor said.

sətʃ lɔɪəlti! wʌns əɡɛn, ʃi wɑz fɔɹs tə ɹiəsɛs əɹ vju ʌv meɪtʃɹim kɔθən.

Such loyalty! Once again, she was forced to reassess her view of Matrim Cauthon.

"bʌt ðɪs ɪz ɪɹɛləvənt," ælθɹ sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp sʌɾənli. wʌn ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz dʒɹu hɪz sɔɹd. ælθɹ ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡɑɹd, ən kɛɹid kwɪkli moʊʃən ət ðə mæn, hu ɹipleɪst ɪz sɔɹd, əʃeɪmd, hɪz aɪz loʊɝd.

"But this is irrelevant," al'Thor said, standing up suddenly. One of the Deathwatch Guards drew his sword. Al'Thor glared at the guard, and Karede quickly motioned at the man, who replaced his sword, ashamed, his eyes lowered.

ælθɹ pleɪst ɪz hæn ɑn ðə teɪbəl, pɑm daʊn. hi lin fɔɹwɝd, tʃɹæpɪŋ tuɑnz aɪz wɪð ɪz oʊn. hu kəd lʊk əweɪ fɹəm ðoʊz ɪntɛns ɡɹeɪ aɪz, laɪk stil? "nʌn ə ðɪs mæɾɝz. mæt dʌzn mæɾɝ. əɹ sɪməlɛɹəɾiz ən əɹ dɪfɝənsɪz də nɑt mæɾɝ. ɔl ðət mæɾɝz ɪz nid. ən aɪ nid ju."

Al'Thor placed his hand on the table, palm down. He leaned forward, trapping Tuon's eyes with his own. Who could look away from those intense gray eyes, like steel? "None of this matters. Mat doesn't matter. Our similarities and our differences do not matter. All that matters is need. And I need you."

hi lin fɔɹwɝd fɝðɝ, lumɪŋ. hɪz fɔɹm dɪdn tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ i sʌɾənli simd ə hʌnʒɹəd fit tɔl. hi spoʊk ɪn ðət seɪm kɑm, pɪɹsɪŋ vɔɪs, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə θɹɛt tə ɪt naʊ. ən ɛdʒ.

He leaned forward further, looming. His form didn't change, but he suddenly seemed a hundred feet tall. He spoke in that same calm, piercing voice, but there was a threat to it now. An edge.

"ju mʌs kɔl ɔf jəɹ ətæks," hi sɛd, nɪɹli ə wɪspɝ. "ju mʌst saɪn ə tʃɹiɾi wɪð mi.

"You must call off your attacks," he said, nearly a whisper. "You must sign a treaty with me.

ðiz ɑɹ nɑt ɹɪkwɛsts. ðeɪ ɑɹ maɪ wɪl."

These are not requests. They are my will."

tuɑn faʊn hɝsɛlf lɔŋɪŋ, sʌɾənli, tə oʊbeɪ hɪm. tə pliz hɪm. ə tʃɹiɾi. ə tʃɹiɾi wəd bi ɛksələnt, ɪt wəd ɡɪv əɹ ə tʃæns tə steɪbəlaɪz əɹ hoʊld ɑn ðə lænz hɪɹ. ʃi kəd plæn haʊ tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɔɹɾɝ bæk ɪn sintʃæn. ʃi kəd ɹəkɹuɾ ən tʃɹeɪn. soʊ mɛni pɑsəbɪləɾiz oʊpən tə hɝ, əz ɪf əɹ maɪnd wɝ sʌɾənli dɪtɝmən tə si ɛvɹi ædvæntɪdʒ ə ði əlaɪəns ən nʌn ə ðə flɔz.

Tuon found herself longing, suddenly, to obey him. To please him. A treaty. A treaty would be excellent, it would give her a chance to stabilize her hold on the lands here. She could plan how to restore order back in Seanchan. She could recruit and train. So many possibilities opened to her, as if her mind were suddenly determined to see every advantage of the alliance and none of the flaws.

ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðoʊz flɔz, skɹæmbəlɪŋ tə si ðə pɹɑbləmz ɪn junaɪɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɪð ðɪs mæn. bʌt ðeɪ bɪkeɪm lɪkwəɾ ɪn əɹ maɪn ən slɪpt əweɪ. ʃi kʊdn snætʃ əm ʌp ən fɔɹm əbdʒɛkʃənz.

She reached for those flaws, scrambling to see the problems in uniting herself with this man. But they became liquid in her mind and slipped away. She couldn't snatch them up and form objections.

ðə pəvɪljən ɡɹu saɪlənt, ðə bɹiz fɔlɪŋ stɪl.

The pavilion grew silent, the breeze falling still.

wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ tə hɝ? ʃi fɛlt ʃɔɹɾ ə bɹɛθ, əz ðoʊ ə weɪt kənstʃɹɪktəɾ əɹ tʃɛst. ʃi fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi kʊdn hɛlp bʌt bɛn bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪl ə ðɪs mæn!

What was happening to her? She felt short of breath, as though a weight constricted her chest. She felt as if she couldn't help but bend before the will of this man!

hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz ɡɹɪm. dɪspaɪt ði æftɝnun laɪt, hɪz feɪs wɑz ʃæɾoʊd, fɑɹ mɔɹ soʊ ðən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls bɪniθ ðə pəvɪljən. hi hɛld əɹ aɪz stɪl, ən əɹ bɹɛθs keɪm kwɪk ən ʃɔɹt. ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ vɪʒən, ʃi θɔt ʃi sɔ sʌmθɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm. ə dɑɹk heɪz, ə heɪloʊ ʌv blæknəs, ɛməneɪɾɪŋ fɹəm hɪm. ɪt wɔɹp ði ɛɹ laɪk ə ɡɹeɪt hit. hɝ θɹoʊt kənstʃɹɪktəd, ən wɝdz wɝ fɔɹmɪŋ. jɛs. jɛs. əl də əz jə æsk. jɛs. aɪ mʌst. aɪ mʌst.

His expression was grim. Despite the afternoon light, his face was shadowed, far more so than everything else beneath the pavilion. He held her eyes still, and her breaths came quick and short. In the corners of her vision, she thought she saw something around him. A dark haze, a halo of blackness, emanating from him. It warped the air like a great heat. Her throat constricted, and words were forming. Yes. Yes. I will do as you ask. Yes. I must. I must.

"noʊ," ʃi sɛd, ðə wɝd bɛɹli ə wɪspɝ.

"No," she said, the word barely a whisper.

hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu dɑɹkɝ, ən ʃi sɔ fjʊɹi ɪn ðə weɪ hi pɹɛst ɪz hæn daʊn, fɪŋɡɝz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ wɪð ðə fɔɹs. ðə weɪ hi klɛntʃt ɪz dʒɔ. ðə weɪ hɪz aɪz oʊpənd waɪɾɝ. sətʃ ɪntɛnsəɾi.

His expression grew darker, and she saw fury in the way he pressed his hand down, fingers trembling with the force. The way he clenched his jaw. The way his eyes opened wider. Such intensity.

"aɪ nid - " hi bɪɡæn.

"I need - " he began.

"noʊ," ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd, kɑnfəɾəns ɡɹoʊɪŋ. "ju wɪl baʊ bɪfɔɹ mi, ɹænd ælθɹ. ɪɾəl nɑt hæpən ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊnd." sətʃ dɑɹknəs! haʊ kəd wʌn mæn kənteɪn ɪt? hi sim tə θɹoʊ ə ʃædoʊ ðə saɪz ʌv ə maʊntən.

"No," she repeated, confidence growing. "You will bow before me, Rand al'Thor. It will not happen the other way around." Such darkness! How could one man contain it? He seemed to throw a shadow the size of a mountain.

ʃi kəd nɑɾ əlaɪ wɪð ðɪs kɹitʃɝ. ðət siθɪŋ heɪtʃɹəd, ɪt tɛɹəfaɪd hɝ, ən tɛɹɝ wɑz ən ɪmoʊʃən wɪð wɪtʃ ʃi wɑz ʌnfəmɪljɝ. ðɪs mæn kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd fɹiɾəm tə də əz i wɪʃt.

She could not ally with this creature. That seething hatred, it terrified her, and terror was an emotion with which she was unfamiliar. This man could not be allowed freedom to do as he wished.

hi hæd tə bi kənteɪnd.

He had to be contained.

hi wɑtʃt əɹ fəɹ ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ. "vɛɹi wɛl," hi sɛd. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz aɪs.

He watched her for a moment longer. "Very well," he said. His voice was ice.

hi spʌn, stɔkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə pəvɪljən, nɑt lʊkɪŋ bæk. hɪz ɑntʊɹɑʒ fɑloʊd; ðeɪ ɔl, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn wɪð ðə bɹeɪd, lʊk dɪstɝbd. əz ɪf ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz wɝn sɝɾən wʌt - əɹ u - ðeɪ fɑloʊɾ ɪn ðɪs mæn.

He spun, stalking away from the pavilion, not looking back. His entourage followed; they all, including the marath'damane with the braid, looked disturbed. As if they themselves weren't certain what - or who - they followed in this man.

tuɑn wɑtʃt ɪm ɡoʊ, pæntɪŋ. ʃi kəd nɑt lɛt ði ʌðɝz si haʊ ɹæɾəld ʃi wɑz. ðeɪ kʊdnt noʊ ðæt, ɪn ðət læs moʊmənt, ʃid fɪɹd hɪm. ʃi wɑtʃt əntɪl ɪz maʊntəd fɪɡjɝ hæd pæs bɪɑn ðə hɪlsaɪdz. ən stɪl əɹ hænz ʃʊk. ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs hɝsɛlf tə spik.

Tuon watched him go, panting. She could not let the others see how rattled she was. They couldn't know that, in that last moment, she'd feared him. She watched until his mounted figure had passed beyond the hillsides. And still her hands shook. She did not trust herself to speak.

noʊbɑdi spoʊk ɪn ðə taɪm ɪt tʊk əɹ tə kɑm hɝsɛlf. pɝhæps ðeɪ wɝ əz ʃeɪkən əz ʃi. pɝhæps ðeɪ sɛnst əɹ wɝi. faɪnəli, lɔŋ æftɝ ælθɹ hæd ɡɔn, tuɑn stʊd. ʃi tɝn ən ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə kəlɛktəd blʌd, dʒɛnɝəlz, soʊlʒɝz ən ɡɑɹdz. "aɪ æm ði ɛmpɹɛs," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə sɑf vɔɪs.

Nobody spoke in the time it took her to calm herself. Perhaps they were as shaken as she. Perhaps they sensed her worry. Finally, long after al'Thor had gone, Tuon stood. She turned and regarded the collected Blood, generals, soldiers and guards. "I am the Empress," she said in a soft voice.

əz wʌn, ðeɪ fɛl tə ðɛɹ niz, ivən ðə haɪ blʌd pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz.

As one, they fell to their knees, even the High Blood prostrating themselves.

ðət wɑz ði oʊnli sɛɹəmoʊni niɾəd. oʊ, ðəɹ wəd bi ə fɔɹməl kɹaʊnɪŋ bæk ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, wɪð pɹoʊsɛʃənz ən pɝeɪdz ən ɑɾiənsəz. ʃi wəɾ æksɛp ðə pɝsənəl oʊðz ʌv əlidʒəns fɹəm itʃ mɛmbɝ ə ðə blʌd, ən wəɾ əv ðə tʃæns - baɪ tʃɹədɪʃən - tə ɛksəkjuɾ ɛni ʌv əm baɪ hɝ oʊn hænd, wɪθaʊt ɹizən, hu ʃi fɛl hæɾ əpoʊzd əɹ əsɛn tə ðə θɹoʊn.

That was the only ceremony needed. Oh, there would be a formal crowning back in Ebou Dar, with processions and parades and audiences. She would accept the personal oaths of allegiance from each member of the Blood, and would have the chance - by tradition - to execute any of them by her own hand, without reason, who she felt had opposed her ascent to the throne.

ðəɹ wəd bi ɔl ə ðəɾ ən mɔɹ. bʌɾ əɹ dɛklɝeɪʃən wɑz ðə tʃɹu kɔɹəneɪʃən. spoʊkən baɪ ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz æftɝ ðə pɪɹiəɾ ə mɔɹnɪŋ.

There would be all of that and more. But her declaration was the true coronation. Spoken by the Daughter of the Nine Moons after the period of mourning.

fɛstɪvəɾiz bɪɡæn ðə moʊmənt ʃi beɪɾ əm ɔl ɹaɪz. ðəɹ wəd bi ə wik ə dʒubəleɪʃən. ə nɛsəsɛɹi dɪstʃɹækʃən. ðə wɝl niɾəd hɝ. ɪt niɾəd ən ɛmpɹɛs. fɹəm ðɪs moʊmən ɑn, ɛvɹiθɪŋ wəd tʃeɪnʒ.

Festivities began the moment she bade them all rise. There would be a week of jubilation. A necessary distraction. The world needed her. It needed an empress. From this moment on, everything would change.

əz ðə dækoʊvæl ɹoʊz ən bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ ðə pɹeɪzəz ə hɝ kɔɹəneɪʃən, tuɑn stɛpt ʌp tə dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən. "pæs ðə wɝd tə dʒɛnɝəl julən," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "tɛl ɪm tə pɹipɛɹ ɪz ətæk əɡɛns ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. wi mʌst stʃɹaɪk əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən kwɪkli. ðɪs mæn kænɑt bi əlaʊd tə ɡeɪn ɛni mɔɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ðən i ɔlɹɛɾi hæz."

As the da'covale rose and began to sing the praises of her coronation, Tuon stepped up to General Galgan. "Pass the word to General Yulan," she said softly. "Tell him to prepare his attack against the marath'damane of Tar Valon. We must strike against the Dragon Reborn, and quickly. This man cannot be allowed to gain any more strength than he already has."

tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɪks

CHAPTER 36

ðə dɛθ ə tuɑn "aɪ bɪɡæn maɪ dʒɝni ɪn tɛɹ," vɛɹɪn sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn mæts bɛs tʃɛɹ, meɪɾ ə dɑɹk wɔlnʌt wɪð ə naɪs tæn pɪloʊ. toʊmɑs tʊk ʌp pəzɪʃən bɪhaɪn hɝ, hæn ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sɔɹd. "maɪ ɡoʊl wɑz tə meɪk maɪ weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

The Death of Tuon "I began my journey in Tear," Verin said, sitting down on Mat's best chair, made of dark walnut with a nice tan pillow. Tomas took up position behind her, hand on the pommel of his sword. "My goal was to make my way to Tar Valon."

"ðɛn haʊ dɪd jə ɛn ʌp hɪɹ?" mæt æskt, stɪl səspɪʃəs əz i siɾəd hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə pɪloʊd bɛntʃ. hi heɪɾəd ðə θɪŋ; ɪt wɑz kəmplitli ɪmpɑsəbəl tə sɪɾ ɑn ɪɾ ɪn ɛni weɪ ðət wɑz kʌmftəɹbəl. pɪloʊz dɪdn hɛlp. sʌmhaʊ, ðeɪ meɪd ðə sit mɔɹ ɑkwɝd. blʌɾi θɪŋ mʌst əv bɪn dɪzaɪn baɪ ɪnseɪn, kɹɔs-aɪd tʃɹɑləks ən bɪl fɹəm ðə boʊnz ə ðə dæmd. ðət wɑz ði oʊnli ɹizənəbəl ɛkspləneɪʃən.

"Then how did you end up here?" Mat asked, still suspicious as he seated himself on the pillowed bench. He hated the thing; it was completely impossible to sit on it in any way that was comfortable. Pillows didn't help. Somehow, they made the seat more awkward. Bloody thing must have been designed by insane, cross-eyed Trollocs and built from the bones of the damned. That was the only reasonable explanation.

hi ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə bɛntʃ, ən nɪɹli kɔl fəɹ ənʌðɝ tʃɛɹ, bʌt vɛɹɪn wɑz kəntɪnjuɪŋ.

He shifted on the bench, and nearly called for another chair, but Verin was continuing.

mændəvwɪn ən tælmɑnz wɝ dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛnt, ðə fɔɹmɝ stændɪŋ wɪð foʊldəɾ ɑɹmz, ðə læɾɝ sɛɾəlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə flɔɹ. tɑm sæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, wɑtʃɪŋ vɛɹɪn wɪð kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ aɪz. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɪn mæts smɔlɝ ɑɾiəns tɛnt, wɪtʃ wɑz ɪntɛndəɾ oʊnli fəɹ ʃɔɹt kɑnfɝənsəz bɪtwin ɔfəsɝz. mæt hædnt wɑntəd tə bɹɪŋ vɛɹɪn tə hɪz æktʃəwəl sɪɾɪŋ tɛnt, əz ɪt wɑz stɪl spɹɛɾ aʊt wɪð ɪz plænz fəɹ ɹeɪɾɪŋ tʃɹʌstɛɹ.

Mandevwin and Talmanes were just inside the tent, the former standing with folded arms, the latter settling himself on the floor. "I ask myself the same question, Master Cauthon," Verin said, smiling, her aging Warder standing behind her chair. "How did I end up here? It certainly wasn't my intention. And yet here I am."

"ju seɪ ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ən æksəɾənt, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ," mændəvwɪn sɛd. "bʌt wɝ spikɪŋ ʌv ə dɪstəns ə sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd liɡz!"

"You say it almost as if it were an accident, Verin Sedai," Mandevwin said. "But we're speaking of a distance of several hundred leagues!"

"plʌs," mæt æɾəd, "ju kən tʃɹævəl. soʊ ɪf jə ɪntɛndəd tə ɡoʊ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ðən waɪ nɑt dʒʌs blʌɾi tʃɹævəl ðəɹ ən bi dʌn wɪð ɪt?"

"ɡʊd kwɛstʃənz," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪndid. maɪɾ aɪ hæv səm ti?"

mæt saɪd, ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn ðə dɛvəl bɛntʃ əɡɛn, ən weɪv fəɹ tælmɑnz tə ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ.

tælmɑnz ɹoʊz ən dʌkt aʊtsaɪd fəɹ ə moʊmən tə pæs ðə wɝd, ðən ɹɪtɝn ən sæt daʊn əɡɛn.

"aɪ faɪn maɪsɛlf kwaɪt pɑɹtʃt." ʃi pɹədʒɛktəd ðət fəmɪljɝ dɪstʃɹæktəɾ ɛɹ ðət wɑz soʊ kɑmən tə sɪstɝz fɹəm ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ. kəz ə ðə hoʊlz ɪn ɪz mɛmɹi, mæts fɝs miɾɪŋ wɪð vɛɹɪn wɑz fʌzi tə hɪm. ɪn fækt, hɪz mɛmɹi ʌv əɹ əɾ ɔl wɑz fʌzi. bʌɾ i dɪd sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi hæd ðə tɛmpɹəmən ʌv ə skɑlɝ.

ðɪs taɪm, stʌɾiɪŋ hɝ, hɝ mænɝɪzəmz sim tu ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd tə hɪm. əz ɪf ʃi wɝ linɪŋ ɑn ðə pɹikənsɛpʃənz əbaʊt bɹaʊnz, juzɪŋ ðɛm. fulɪŋ pipəl, laɪk ə stʃɹit pɝfɔɹmɝ teɪkɪŋ ɪn kʌntʃɹi bɔɪz wɪð ə klɛvɝ ɡeɪm ə θɹi-kɑɹd ʃʌfəl.

ɪn ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm, juɾ əndaʊɾɪdli bi ðə moʊs paʊɝfli tɑvɝən ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl əlaɪv. pɹɑbli ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl tə hæv lɪvd ɪn sɛntʃɝiz."

In any other time, you'd undoubtedly be the most powerfully ta'veren individual alive. Probably the most powerful to have lived in centuries."

mæt ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə bɛntʃ. blʌɾi æʃəz, hi heɪɾəd ðə weɪ ðət meɪɾ ɪm lʊk əz ɪf i wɑz skwɝmɪŋ. meɪbi hi ʃəd dʒʌst stæn ʌp. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, vɛɹɪn?" hi sɛɾ ɪnstɛd. hi foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ən tʃɹaɪd tə ət lis pɹitɛn ðəɾ i wɑz kʌmftəɹbəl.

Mat shifted on the bench. Bloody ashes, he hated the way that made him look as if he was squirming. Maybe he should just stand up. "What are you talking about, Verin?" he said instead. He folded his arms and tried to at least pretend that he was comfortable.

"aɪm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ jə jæŋk mi hæfweɪ əkɹɔs ðə kɑntənənt." hɝ smaɪl waɪɾənd əz ə soʊlʒɝ ɛntɝd wɪð ə stimɪŋ kʌp ə mɪn ti. ʃi tʊk ɪt ɡɹeɪtfəli, ən ðə soʊlʒɝ ɹitʃɹiɾəd.

"I'm talking about how you yanked me halfway across the continent." Her smile widened as a soldier entered with a steaming cup of mint tea. She took it gratefully, and the soldier retreated.

"jæŋk ju?" mæt sɛd. "ju wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi."

"Yanked you?" Mat said. "You were looking for me."

"oʊnli æftɝ aɪ dɪtɝmən ðət ðə pæɾɝn wɑz tʌɡɪŋ mi sʌmwɛɹ." vɛɹɪn blu ɑn əɹ ti.

"Only after I determined that the Pattern was tugging me somewhere." Verin blew on her tea.

"ðæt mɛn jə əɹ pɛɹɪn. ɪt kʊdn əv bɪn ɹændz fɔlt, sɪns aɪd bɪn eɪbəl tə liv ðət wʌn izəli."

"That meant you or Perrin. It couldn't have been Rand's fault, since I'd been able to leave that one easily."

"ɹænd?" mæt æskt, dɪsmɪsɪŋ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ flæʃ ə kʌlɝz. "ju wɝ wɪð hɪm?"

"Rand?" Mat asked, dismissing yet another flash of colors. "You were with him?"

vɛɹɪn nɑɾəd.

Verin nodded.

"haʊ . . . dɪɾ i sim?" mæt sɛd. "ɪz i . . . jə noʊ. . . ."

"How . . . did he seem?" Mat said. "Is he . . . you know. . . ."

"mæd?" vɛɹɪn æskt.

"Mad?" Verin asked.

mæt nɑɾəd.

Mat nodded.

"aɪm əfɹeɪd soʊ," vɛɹɪn sɛd, lɪps daʊntɝnɪŋ slaɪtli. "aɪ θɪŋk hiz stɪl ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɪmsɛlf, haʊɛvɝ."

"I'm afraid so," Verin said, lips downturning slightly. "I think he's still in control of himself, however."

"blʌɾi wʌn paʊɝ," mæt sɛd, ɹitʃɪŋ bɪniθ ɪz ʃɝt tə tʌtʃ ðə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ fɑkshɛd mədæljən.

"Bloody One Power," Mat said, reaching beneath his shirt to touch the comforting foxhead medallion.

vɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌp. "oʊ, aɪm nɑt kənvɪns jʌŋ ælθɹz pɹɑbləmz ɑɹ kəmplitli du tə ðə paʊɝ, meɪtʃɹim. mɛni wəd laɪk tə bleɪm ɪz tɛmpɹəmən ɑn seɪɾɪn, bʌt tə də ðəɾ ɪz tə ɪɡnɔɹ ði ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl stʃɹɛsəz ðət wiv sɛɾəld ɑn ðət pʊɹ bɔɪz ʃoʊldɝz."

Verin looked up. "Oh, I'm not convinced young al'Thor's problems are completely due to the Power, Matrim. Many would like to blame his temperament on saidin, but to do that is to ignore the incredible stresses that we've settled on that poor boy's shoulders."

mæt ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, ɡlænsɪŋ ət tɑm.

Mat raised an eyebrow, glancing at Thom.

"iðɝ weɪ," vɛɹɪn sɪpt əɹ ti, "wʌn kænɑt bleɪm tu mʌtʃ ɑn ðə teɪnt, əz ɪɾəl noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əfɛk hɪm."

"Either way," Verin sipped her tea, "one cannot blame too much on the taint, as it will no longer affect him."

"ɪt woʊnt?" mæt æskt. "hiz dɪsaɪɾɪd tə stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ?"

"It won't?" Mat asked. "He's decided to stop channeling?"

ʃi læft. "ə fɪʃ wəd sunɝ stɑp swɪmɪŋ. noʊ, ðə teɪnt wɪl noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əfɛkt ɪm kəz ðə teɪn ɪz noʊ mɔɹ. ælθɹ klɛnz seɪɾɪn."

She laughed. "A fish would sooner stop swimming. No, the taint will no longer affect him because the taint is no more. Al'Thor cleansed saidin."

"wʌt?" mæt æskt ʃɑɹpli, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp.

"What?" Mat asked sharply, sitting up.

vɛɹɪn sɪpt əɹ ti.

Verin sipped her tea.

"ɑɹ jə sɪɹiəs?" mæt æskt.

"Are you serious?" Mat asked.

"kwaɪt," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd.

"Quite," she replied.

mæt ɡlænst ət tɑm əɡɛn. ðən i plʌkt əɾ ɪz koʊɾ ən ɹæn ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ.

Mat glanced at Thom again. Then he plucked at his coat and ran a hand through his hair.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" vɛɹɪn æskt wɪð əmjuzmənt.

"What are you doing?" Verin asked with amusement.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," mæt sɛd, filɪŋ ʃipɪʃ. "aɪ ɡɛs aɪ dʒʌs θɪŋk aɪ ʃəd fil dɪfɹənt, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ. ðə hoʊl wɝld ʌp ən tʃeɪnʒd ɑn ʌs, dɪdn ɪt?"

"I don't know," Mat said, feeling sheepish. "I guess I just think I should feel different, or something. The whole world up and changed on us, didn't it?"

"ju kəd seɪ ðæt," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "ðoʊ aɪ wəɾ ɑɹɡju ðət ðə klɛnzɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɪz mɔɹ laɪk ə pɛbəl θɹoʊn ɪndə ə pɑnd. ðə ɹɪpəlz wɪl teɪk səm taɪm tə ɹitʃ ðə ʃɔɹ."

"You could say that," Verin said, "though I would argue that the cleansing itself is more like a pebble thrown into a pond. The ripples will take some time to reach the shore."

"ə pɛbəl?" mæt æskt. "ə pɛbəl?"

"A pebble?" Mat asked. "A pebble?"

"wɛl, pɝhæps mɔɹ ʌv ə boʊldɝ."

"Well, perhaps more of a boulder."

"ə blʌɾi maʊntən ɪf jə æsk mi," mæt mʌɾɝd. hi sɛɾəld bæk ɑn ði ɑfəl bɛntʃ.

"A bloody mountain if you ask me," Mat muttered. He settled back on the awful bench.

vɛɹɪn tʃʌkəld. fleɪmɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. dɪd ðeɪv tə bi laɪk ðæt? ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli ənʌðɝ oʊθ ðeɪ tʊk ən toʊl noʊbɑdi əbaʊt, sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð æktɪŋ mɪstɪɹiəs. hi stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. "wʌt wɑz ðət tʃʌkəl fɔɹ?" hi faɪnəli dɪmændəd.

Verin chuckled. Flaming Aes Sedai. Did they have to be like that? It was probably another oath they took and told nobody about, something to do with acting mysterious. He stared at her. "What was that chuckle for?" he finally demanded.

"nʌθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ mɪɹli səspɛk ðət jəl sun fil ə lɪɾəl ʌv wʌɾ aɪ dɪd ðɪs læs mʌnθ."

"Nothing," she said. "I merely suspect that you will soon feel a little of what I did this last month."

"wɪtʃ wɑz?"

"Which was?"

"wɛl," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ bɪliv aɪ wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðət bɪfɔɹ wi ɡɑt saɪdtʃɹækt ɑn ɪɹɛləvən tɑpɪks."

"Well," she said. "I believe I was talking about that before we got sidetracked on irrelevant topics."

"ɑn ðə fleɪmɪŋ klɛnzɪŋ ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs," mæt mʌɾɝd. "ɑnəsli."

"On the flaming cleansing of the True Source," Mat muttered. "Honestly."

"aɪ ɪkspɪɹiəns ðə moʊs kjʊɹiəs ʌv ɪvɛns," vɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud. ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ mæt, ʌv kɔɹs. "ju meɪ nɑt bi əwɛɹ ə ðɪs, bʌɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə tʃɹævəl fɹəm ə loʊkeɪʃən, jə nid tə spɛn taɪm ɪn ɪt. juʒəwəli, stɑpɪŋ ɪn ə pleɪs fəɹ ən ivnɪŋ ɪz ɪnʌf. kɑnsəkwənli, æftɝ pɑɹɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən, aɪ meɪd maɪ weɪ tə ə nɪɹbaɪ vɪlədʒ ən tʊk ə ɹum ət ði ɪn. aɪ sɛɾəld daʊn, lɝnɪŋ ðə ɹum ən pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ.

"I experienced the most curious of events," Verin continued. Ignoring Mat, of course. "You may not be aware of this, but in order to Travel from a location, you need to spend time in it. Usually, stopping in a place for an evening is enough. Consequently, after parting from the Dragon, I made my way to a nearby village and took a room at the inn. I settled down, learning the room and preparing to open a Gateway in the morning.

"ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt, haʊɛvɝ, ði ɪnkipɝ ɝaɪvd. hi ɪkspleɪnd wɪð ʃəɡɹɪn ðəɾ aɪ niɾəd tə bi muv tə ənʌðɝ ɹum. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðəɾ ə lik hæd bɪn dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ðə ɹuf əbʌv maɪ ɹum, ən ɪt wəd sun sip θɹu maɪ silɪŋ. aɪ pɹətɛstəd, bʌɾ i wɑz ɪnsɪstənt.

"In the middle of the night, however, the innkeeper arrived. He explained with chagrin that I needed to be moved to another room. It appeared that a leak had been discovered in the roof above my room, and it would soon seep through my ceiling. I protested, but he was insistent.

"æn soʊ aɪ muvd əkɹɔs ðə hɔl ən bɪɡæn lɝnɪŋ ðət ɹum. dʒʌst wən aɪ wɑz filɪŋ aɪ nu ɪt wɛl ɪnʌf tə oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ, aɪ wɑz ɪntɝʌptɪɾ əɡɛn. ðɪs taɪm, ði ɪnkipɝ - mɔɹ ɪmbɛɹəst  - ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ ɪz waɪf hæd lɔst əɹ ɹɪŋ ɪn ðət ɹum dʊɹɪŋ ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ klinɪŋ. ðə wʊmən əwoʊk ɪn ðə naɪɾ ən wɑz vɛɹi əpsɛt. ði ɪnkipɝ - lʊkɪŋ kwaɪt taɪɝd - əpɑlədʒɛɾɪkli wɑntəd tə muv mi əɡɛn."

"And so I moved across the hall and began learning that room. Just when I was feeling I knew it well enough to open a gateway, I was interrupted again. This time, the innkeeper - more embarrassed  - explained that his wife had lost her ring in that room during early morning cleaning. The woman awoke in the night and was very upset. The innkeeper - looking quite tired - apologetically wanted to move me again."

"ænd?" mæt æskt. "koʊɪnsɪɾəns, vɛɹɪn."

"And?" Mat asked. "Coincidence, Verin."

ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm, ðən smaɪld əz i ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə bɛntʃ əɡɛn. bɝn ɪɾ ɔl, hi wɑzn skwɝmɪŋ!

She raised an eyebrow at him, then smiled as he shifted on the bench again. Burn it all, he wasn't squirming!

"aɪ ɹəfjuz tə bi muvd, meɪtʃɹim," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ toʊl ði ɪnkipɝ i wɑz kwaɪt wɛlkəm tə sɝtʃ ðə ɹum æftɝ aɪ lɛft, ən pɹɑməs ðəɾ aɪ wəd nɑt teɪk ɛni ɹɪŋz aɪ dɪskʌvɝd wɪð mi. ðən aɪ fɝmli ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ ɑn hɪm." ʃi sɪpt əɹ dʒɹɪŋk. "ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, ði ɪn kɑt faɪɝ - ə koʊl fɹəm ðə hɑɹθ ɹoʊl tə ðə flɔɹ ən ɛndəɾ ʌp bɝnɪŋ ði ɪntaɪɝ pleɪs tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪskeɪpt, fɔɹtʃənətli, bʌt ði ɪn wɑz ə lɔs. taɪɝɾ ən blɪɹi-aɪd, toʊmɑs ən aɪ hæd tə muv ɑn tə ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ ən faɪn ɹumz ðəɹ ɪnstɛd."

"I refused to be moved, Matrim," she said. "I told the innkeeper he was quite welcome to search the room after I left, and promised that I would not take any rings I discovered with me. Then I firmly shut the door on him." She sipped her drink. "A few minutes later, the inn caught fire - a coal from the hearth rolled to the floor and ended up burning the entire place to the ground. Everyone escaped, fortunately, but the inn was a loss. Tired and bleary-eyed, Tomas and I had to move on to the next village and find rooms there instead."

"soʊ?" mæt sɛd. "stɪl saʊnz laɪk ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns."

"So?" Mat said. "Still sounds like a coincidence."

"ðɪs kəntɪnjud fəɹ θɹi deɪz," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ wɑz ɪntɝʌptɪɾ ivən wən aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə lɝn ə pleɪs aʊtsaɪɾ ə bɪldɪŋ. ɹændəm pæsɝzbi æskɪŋ tə ʃɛɹ ðə faɪɝ, ə fɔlɪŋ tʃɹi kɹæʃɪŋ daʊn ɪn kæmp, ə flɑk ə ʃip wɑndɝɪŋ baɪ, ən aɪsəleɪɾəd stɔɹm. vɛɹiəs ɹændəm ɪvɛns ɔlweɪz kəntʃɹaɪv tə kip mi fɹəm lɝnɪŋ ði ɛɹiə."

"This continued for three days," Verin said. "I was interrupted even when I tried to learn a place outside a building. Random passersby asking to share the fire, a falling tree crashing down in camp, a flock of sheep wandering by, an isolated storm. Various random events always contrived to keep me from learning the area."

tælmɑnz wɪsəl sɔfli. vɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "itʃ taɪm aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə lɝn ən ɛɹiə, sʌmθɪŋ wɛn ɹɔŋ. aɪ wɑz ɪnɛvəɾəbli muv fəɹ səm ɹizən. haʊɛvɝ, wən aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd aɪ wɑzn gɑnə də ɛniθɪŋ tə lɝn ə loʊkeɪʃən ən wɑzn plænɪŋ tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ, nʌθɪŋ hæpənd. ənʌðɝ pɝsən maɪɾ əv sɪmpli muvd ɑn ən ɡɪvən ʌp ɑn tʃɹævlɪŋ fəɹ ðə taɪm, bʌt maɪ neɪtʃɝ əsɝɾəd ɪtsɛlf, ən aɪ faʊn maɪsɛlf stʌɾiɪŋ ðə fənɑmənɑn. ɪt wɑz kwaɪt ɹɛɡjəlɝ."

Talmanes whistled softly. Verin nodded. "Each time I tried to learn an area, something went wrong. I was inevitably moved for some reason. However, when I decided I wasn't going to do anything to learn a location and wasn't planning to make a gateway, nothing happened. Another person might have simply moved on and given up on Traveling for the time, but my nature asserted itself, and I found myself studying the phenomenon. It was quite regular."

blʌɾi æʃəz. ðət wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ɹænd wɑz səpoʊz tə də tə pipəl. nɑt mæt. "baɪ jəɹ əkaʊnt, jə ʃəd stɪl bi ɪn tiɹ."

Bloody ashes. That was the sort of thing Rand was supposed to do to people. Not Mat. "By your account, you should still be in Tear."

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ sun stɑɹɾəd tə fil ə tʌɡɪŋ ɑn mi. sʌmθɪŋ pʊlɪŋ mi, jæŋkɪŋ mi. əz ɪf. . . ."

"Yes," she said, "but I soon started to feel a tugging on me. Something pulling me, yanking me. As if. . . ."

mæt ʃɪftəɾ əɡɛn. "æz ɪf sʌmwʌnz ɡɑɾ ə blʌɾi fɪʃhʊk ɪnsaɪɾ ə ju? ən ɪz stændɪŋ fɑɹ əweɪ, pʊlɪŋ dʒɛnli - bʌɾ ɪnsɪstənli - ɑn ɪt?"

Mat shifted again. "As if someone's got a bloody fishhook inside of you? And is standing far away, pulling gently - but insistently - on it?"

"jɛs," vɛɹɪn sɛd. ʃi smaɪld. "wʌɾ ə klɛvɝ dɪskɹɪpʃən."

"Yes," Verin said. She smiled. "What a clever description."

mæt dɪdn ɹɪspɑnd.

Mat didn't respond.

"aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə juz mɔɹ məndeɪn minz tə meɪk maɪ vɔɪədʒ. aɪ θɔt ðət meɪbi maɪ ɪnəbɪlɪɾi tə tʃɹævəl hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ælθɹz pɹɑksɪməɾi, əɹ pɝhæps ðə ɡɹædʒuəl ənɹævəlɪŋ ə ðə pæɾɝn du tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz ɪnfluəns. aɪ sɪkjʊɹɾ ə pleɪs ɪn ə mɝtʃən kæɹəvæn tʃɹævlɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd təwɔɹd kɛɹhin. ðeɪ hæɾ ən ɛmpti wæɡən ðeɪ wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə ɹɛn fəɹ ə ɹizənəbəl ɹeɪt. aɪ wɑz kwaɪt fətiɡd fɹəm maɪ deɪz spɛn steɪɪŋ ʌp ɔl aʊɝz kəz ə faɪɝz, kɹaɪɪŋ beɪbiz ən kɑnstən muvz fɹəm wʌn ɪn ɹum tə ənʌðɝ. əz sʌtʃ, aɪ fɪɹ aɪ slɛp mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ ðən aɪ ʃəd hæv. toʊmɑs næpt əz wɛl.

"I decided to use more mundane means to make my voyage. I thought that maybe my inability to Travel had something to do with al'Thor's proximity, or perhaps the gradual unraveling of the Pattern due to the Dark One's influence. I secured a place in a merchant caravan traveling northward toward Cairhien. They had an empty wagon they were willing to rent for a reasonable rate. I was quite fatigued from my days spent staying up all hours because of fires, crying babies and constant moves from one inn room to another. As such, I fear I slept much longer than I should have. Tomas napped as well.

"wɛn wi əwoʊk, wi wɝ sɝpɹaɪz tə dɪskʌvɝ ðət ðə kæɹəvæn hæd teɪkən ə tɝn tə ðə nɔɹθwɛst ɪnstɛɾ ə hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd kɛɹhin. aɪ spoʊk wɪð ðə kæɹəvæn mæstɝ, ən i ɪkspleɪn ðət hid ɹəsivd ə læst-mɪnət tɪp ðəɾ ɪz ɡʊdz wəd fɛtʃ ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ pɹaɪs ɪn mʊɹændi ðən ɪn kɛɹhin. əz i kənsɪɾɝd ɪt, hi mɛnʃən ðəɾ i ɹɪli ʃʊɾə toʊl mi əbaʊt ðə tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd slɪpt ɪz maɪnd."

Skimming is an inferior substitute for Traveling, but does not have the same limitation of knowing the area. mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. wɛl, meɪbi.

sɪns ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ aɪ lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. wʌt dʌz ɪt tʃeɪnʒ?"

Since the day before I left the Two Rivers. What does it change?"

"θɝɾi deɪz," ʃi sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ, ðən ɹeɪzd ə fɪŋɡɝ tə kʌɾ ɔf ɪz əbdʒɛkʃən. "ə kɑmpɹəmaɪz, mæt.

"Thirty days," she said, rising, then raised a finger to cut off his objection. "A compromise, Mat.

əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ θɪŋk jə ʃæl faɪn mi tə bi fɑɹ mɔɹ əmɛnəbəl tə ðoʊz ðən moʊst." ʃi hɛld aʊɾ əɹ hænd.

Among Aes Sedai, I think you shall find me to be far more amenable to those than most." She held out her hand.

θɝɾi deɪz. hi kəd weɪt θɝɾi deɪz. hi lʊkt ət ðə lɛɾɝ ɪn ɪz hænz. hi kəd ɹɪzɪst oʊpənɪŋ ɪt, ən θɝɾi deɪz ʌv weɪɾɪŋ dɪdn ɹɪli luz ɪm ɛni taɪm. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ ðən hid teɪk tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn ɑn ɪz oʊn. ɪn fækt, ðɪs wɑz ə blʌɾi bɑɹɡən! hi niɾəd ə fju wiks tə ɡɛt ðə dʒɹæɡənz ɡoʊɪŋ, ən i wɑntəd taɪm tə faɪn aʊt mɔɹ əbaʊt ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ ən ðə sneɪks ən fɑksəz. tɑm kʊdn kəmpleɪn - wən ɪt wəd teɪk əm tu wiks tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn ɛniweɪ.

Thirty days. He could wait thirty days. He looked at the letter in his hands. He could resist opening it, and thirty days of waiting didn't really lose him any time. It was only a little longer than he'd take to reach Caemlyn on his own. In fact, this was a bloody bargain! He needed a few weeks to get the dragons going, and he wanted time to find out more about the Tower of Ghenjei and the snakes and foxes. Thom couldn't complain - when it would take them two weeks to reach Caemlyn anyway.

vɛɹɪn aɪd hɪm, ə hɪn ʌv wɝi ɑn əɹ feɪs. hi kʊdn lɛɾ əɹ noʊ haʊ plizd i wɑz. lɛɾ ə wʊmən noʊ ðæt, ən ʃid faɪn səm weɪ tə meɪk jə peɪ hɝ bæk.

Verin eyed him, a hint of worry on her face. He couldn't let her know how pleased he was. Let a woman know that, and she'd find some way to make you pay her back.

"θɝɾi deɪz," mæt sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli, teɪkɪŋ əɹ hænd, "bʌɾ ət ði ɛn ə ðɛm, aɪ kən ɡoʊ."

"Thirty days," Mat said reluctantly, taking her hand, "but at the end of them, I can go."

"ɔɹ jə kən oʊpən ðə lɛɾɝ æftɝ tɛn deɪz," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "æn də wʌɾ ɪt sɛz. wʌn ə ðə tu, meɪtʃɹim. aɪ hæv jəɹ wɝd?"

"Or you can open the letter after ten days," Verin said, "and do what it says. One of the two, Matrim. I have your word?"

"ju du," hi sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪm nɑt gɑnə oʊpən ðə blʌɾi lɛɾɝ. aɪm gɑnə weɪt θɝɾi deɪz, ðən bi ɔf ɑn maɪ bɪznəs."

"You do," he said. "But I'm not going to open the bloody letter. I'm going to wait thirty days, then be off on my business."

"wi ʃæl si," ʃi sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf ən ɹilisɪŋ ɪz hænd. ʃi foʊldəɾ ʌp ðə pɪktʃɝ ə hɪm, ðən tʊk ə smɔl lɛðɝ-baʊn sætʃəl fɹəm əɹ pɑkət. ʃi oʊpən ɪt, slaɪɾɪŋ ðə pɪktʃɝ ɪnsaɪd, ən əz ʃi dɪd, hi noʊɾəst ðət ʃi hæɾ ə smɔl stæk ə foʊldəd, sil pisəz ə peɪpɝ ɪnsaɪd dʒʌs laɪk ðə wʌn i wɑz hoʊldɪŋ. wʌt wɑz ðə pɝpəs ə ðoʊz?

"We shall see," she said, smiling to herself and releasing his hand. She folded up the picture of him, then took a small leather-bound satchel from her pocket. She opened it, sliding the picture inside, and as she did, he noticed that she had a small stack of folded, sealed pieces of paper inside just like the one he was holding. What was the purpose of those?

wʌns ðə lɛɾɝz wɝ seɪfli tʌkt ɪn əɹ pɑkət, ʃi tʊk aʊɾ ə kɑɹv pis ə tʃɹænslusən stoʊn  - ə bɹutʃ, ʃeɪp laɪk ə lɪli. "bɪɡɪn bɹeɪkɪŋ daʊn jəɹ kæmp, meɪtʃɹim. aɪ nid tə meɪk jəɹ ɡeɪtweɪ əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. aɪ maɪsɛlf nid tə tʃɹævəl ʃɔɹtli."

Once the letters were safely tucked in her pocket, she took out a carved piece of translucent stone  - a brooch, shaped like a lily. "Begin breaking down your camp, Matrim. I need to make your gateway as soon as possible. I myself need to Travel shortly."

"faɪn." mæt lʊk daʊn ət ðə sild, foʊldəd peɪpɝ ɪn ɪz hænz. waɪ wɑz vɛɹɪn biɪŋ soʊ kɹɪptɪk?

"Fine." Mat looked down at the sealed, folded paper in his hands. Why was Verin being so cryptic?

bɝn ɪt! hi θɔt. aɪm nɑt gɑnə oʊpən ɪt. aɪm nɑt. "mændəvwɪn," hi sɛd. "ɡɛt vɛɹɪn sədaɪ hɝ oʊn tɛn tə weɪɾ ɪn əz wi bɹeɪk kæmp ən əsaɪn ə kʌpəl ə soʊlʒɝz tə fɛtʃ fəɹ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ʃi nidz. ɔlsoʊ, ɪnfɔɹm ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət ʃiz hɪɹ. ðəl pɹɑbli bi ɪntʃɹəstəd tə hɪɹ ə hɝ ɝaɪvəl, ɛɛs sədaɪ biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Burn it! he thought. I'm not going to open it. I'm not. "Mandevwin," he said. "Get Verin Sedai her own tent to wait in as we break camp and assign a couple of soldiers to fetch for her anything she needs. Also, inform the other Aes Sedai that she's here. They'll probably be interested to hear of her arrival, Aes Sedai being Aes Sedai."

mæt tʌk ðə foʊldəd peɪpɝ ɪndə hɪz bɛlt, ðən stɑɹɾəd tə liv. "æn əv sʌmbɑɾi bɝn ðət blʌɾi bɛntʃ. aɪ kæn bɪliv wi kɑɹɾɪd ðə θɪŋ ðɪs fɑɹ."

Mat tucked the folded paper into his belt, then started to leave. "And have somebody burn that bloody bench. I can't believe we carted the thing this far."

tuɑn wɑz dɛd. ɡɔn, kæst əsaɪd, fɝɡɑɾən. tuɑn hæd bɪn ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. ʃi wɑz naʊ dʒʌst ə noʊteɪʃən ɪn ðə hɪstɝiz.

Tuon was dead. Gone, cast aside, forgotten. Tuon had been the Daughter of the Nine Moons. She was now just a notation in the histories.

fɔɹtwoʊnə wɑz ɛmpɹɛs.

Fortuona was empress.

fɔɹtwoʊnə æθeɪɪm dɛvi pɛndʒɹæɡ kɪs ðə soʊlʒɝ laɪtli ɑn ðə fɔɹhɛɾ əz i nɛlt, hɛd baʊd, ɑn ðə ʃɔɹt ɡɹæs. ðə mʌɡi ɔltɑɹən hit meɪɾ ɪt fil əz ɪf sʌmɝ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɝaɪvd, bʌt ðə ɡɹæs - wɪtʃ hæd sim lʌʃ ən fʊl ə laɪf dʒʌst wiks bɪfɔɹ - hæd ɡɹoʊn stʌntɪɾ ən wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə jɛloʊ. wɛɹ wɝ ðə widz ən θɪsəlz? ɹisənli sidz dɪdn spɹaʊɾ əz ðeɪ ʃʊd.

Fortuona Athaem Devi Paendrag kissed the soldier lightly on the forehead as he knelt, head bowed, on the short grass. The muggy Altaran heat made it feel as if summer had already arrived, but the grass - which had seemed lush and full of life just weeks before - had grown stunted and was beginning to yellow. Where were the weeds and thistles? Recently seeds didn't sprout as they should.

laɪk ɡɹeɪn, ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ bæd, daɪɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ tʃɹuli keɪm əlaɪv.

Like grain, they were going bad, dying before they truly came alive.

ðə soʊlʒɝ bɪfɔɹ fɔɹtwoʊnə wɑz wʌn ə faɪv. bɪhaɪn ðoʊz faɪv stʊd tu hʌnʒɹəd mɛmbɝz ə ðə fɪsts ə hɛvən - ðə moʊst ɪliɾ ə hɝ ətæk fɔɹsɪz. ðeɪ wɔɹ dɑɹk lɛðɝ bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlmz ə laɪt wʊɾ ən lɛðɝ, ʃeɪp laɪk ɪnsɛks. boʊθ hɛlmz ən bɹɛstpleɪts wɝ ɛmbleɪzənd wɪð ðə saɪn ə ðə klɛntʃt fɪst. fɪfti sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn pɛɹz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ dɑli ən əɹ sʌldəm mæləhəvænə, hum fɔɹtwoʊnə hæd ɡɪvən tə ðə kɑz. ʃi hæd fɛl ðə nid tə sækɹəfaɪs sʌmθɪŋ pɝsənəl tə ðɪs moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt ə mɪʃənz.

The soldier before Fortuona was one of five. Behind those five stood two hundred members of the Fists of Heaven - the most elite of her attack forces. They wore dark leather breastplates and helms of light wood and leather, shaped like insects. Both helms and breastplates were emblazoned with the sign of the clenched fist. Fifty sul'dam and damane pairs, including Dali and her sul'dam Malahavana, whom Fortuona had given to the cause. She had felt the need to sacrifice something personal to this most important of missions.

hʌnʒɹədz ə tɔɹeɪkən mɪld ɪn ðə pɛnz bɪhaɪnd, wɔk baɪ ðɛɹ hænlɝz, hu wɝ pɹipɛɹɪŋ əm fəɹ ðə flaɪt tə kʌm. ɔlɹɛɾi, ə flɑk ə ɹeɪkən sɝkəld əbʌv, ɡɹeɪsfəl.

Hundreds of to'raken milled in the pens behind, walked by their handlers, who were preparing them for the flight to come. Already, a flock of raken circled above, graceful.

fɔɹtwoʊnə lʊk daʊn ət ðə soʊlʒɝ bɪfɔɹ hɝ, leɪɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd, wɛɹ ʃi hæd kɪs hɪm. "meɪ jəɹ dɛθ bɹɪŋ vɪktɝi," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, spikɪŋ ðə ɹɪtʃuəl wɝdz. "meɪ jəɹ naɪf dʒɹɔ blʌd. meɪ jəɹ tʃɪlʒɹən sɪŋ jəɹ pɹeɪzəz əntɪl ðə faɪnəl dɔn."

Fortuona looked down at the soldier before her, laying her fingers on his forehead, where she had kissed him. "May your death bring victory," she said softly, speaking the ritual words. "May your knife draw blood. May your children sing your praises until the final dawn."

hi baʊɾ ɪz hɛd fɝðɝ. laɪk ðə fɔɹ ʌðɝz ɪn ðə ɹoʊ, hi wɔɹ blæk lɛðɝ. θɹi naɪvz hʌŋ fɹəm ɪz bɛlt, ən i hæd noʊ kloʊk əɹ hɛlm. hi wɑz ə smɔl mæn - ɔl mɛmbɝz ə ðə fɪsts ə hɛvən wɝ smɔl ən kɑmpækt, ən oʊvɝ hæf ɪn ðɪs ɡɹup wɝ wɪmən. weɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz ən ɪʃu fəɹ ðoʊz feɪsɪŋ mɪʃənz juzɪŋ tɔɹeɪkən. ɪn ə ɹeɪd, tu smɔl, wɛl-tʃɹeɪn soʊlʒɝz wɝ pɹɛfɝəbəl tə wʌn lʌmbɝɪŋ hʌlk ɪn hɛvi ɑɹmɝ.

He bowed his head further. Like the four others in the row, he wore black leather. Three knives hung from his belt, and he had no cloak or helm. He was a small man - all members of the Fists of Heaven were small and compact, and over half in this group were women. Weight was always an issue for those facing missions using to'raken. In a raid, two small, well-trained soldiers were preferable to one lumbering hulk in heavy armor.

ɪt wɑz ɝli ivnɪŋ, ðə sʌn dʒʌst sɛɾɪŋ. lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl julən - hu wəd lɛd ðə stʃɹaɪk fɔɹs pɝsənəli - fɛlt ɪt bɛs tə teɪk flaɪt leɪɾ ɪn ðə deɪ. ðɛɹ əsɔlt wəd bɪɡɪn ɪn dɑɹknəs, ʃɹaʊɾɪŋ ɪt fɹəm ðoʊz u maɪt bi wɑtʃɪŋ ðə hɝaɪzən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. wʌns, ðə kɑʃən wʊɾə bɪn ənnɛsəsɛɹi. wʌt mæɾɝ ɪf pipəl ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ sɔ hʌnʒɹədz ə tɔɹeɪkən teɪk tə ðə skaɪz? nuz kəd nɛvɝ tʃɹævəl əz kwɪkli əz ɹeɪkən wɪŋz.

It was early evening, the sun just setting. Lieutenant-General Yulan - who would lead the strike force personally - felt it best to take flight late in the day. Their assault would begin in darkness, shrouding it from those who might be watching the horizon in Ebou Dar. Once, the caution would have been unnecessary. What matter if people in Ebou Dar saw hundreds of to'raken take to the skies? News could never travel as quickly as raken wings.

bʌt ðɛɹ ɛnəmiz kəd tʃɹævəl fɑɹ mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən ðeɪ ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə. bi ɪt tɛɹæŋɡɹil, wiv əɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ðət ɡeɪv ðə paʊɝ, ɪt wɑz ə dɪstɪŋk deɪnʒɝ. bɛɾɝ tə juz ɔl stɛlθ. ðə flaɪt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn wəd teɪk sɛvɹəl deɪz.

But their enemies could travel far more quickly than they should be able to. Be it ter'angreal, weave or something else that gave the power, it was a distinct danger. Better to use all stealth. The flight to Tar Valon would take several days.

fɔɹtwoʊnə muv tə ðə nɛkst soʊlʒɝ ɪn ðə laɪn ə faɪv. ðə wʊmənz blæk hɛɹ wɑz bɹeɪɾɪd.

Fortuona moved to the next soldier in the line of five. The woman's black hair was braided.

fɔɹtwoʊnə kɪst əɹ ɑn ðə fɔɹhɛd, seɪɪŋ ðə seɪm ɹɪtʃuəl wɝdz. ðiz faɪv wɝ blʌdnaɪvz. ðə pjʊɹ blæk stoʊn ɹɪŋ itʃ wʌn wɔɹ wɑz ə spɛʃəlaɪz tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət wəd ɡɹæn əm stʃɹɛŋkθ ən spid, ən wəd ʃɹaʊɾ əm ɪn dɑɹknəs, əlaʊɪŋ əm tə blɛn ɪndə ʃædoʊz.

Fortuona kissed her on the forehead, saying the same ritual words. These five were Bloodknives. The pure black stone ring each one wore was a specialized ter'angreal that would grant them strength and speed, and would shroud them in darkness, allowing them to blend into shadows.

ði ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl əbɪləɾiz keɪm əɾ ə kɑst, haʊɛvɝ, fəɹ ðə ɹɪŋz litʃt laɪf fɹəm ðɛɹ hoʊsts, kɪlɪŋ əm ɪn ə mæɾɝ ə deɪz. ɹimuvɪŋ ðə ɹɪŋ wəd sloʊ ðət pɹɑsɛs slaɪtli, bʌt wʌns æktəveɪɾəd -  dʌn baɪ tʌtʃɪŋ ə dʒɹɑp ʌv wʌnz oʊn blʌd tə ðə stoʊn ɹɪŋ waɪl wɛɹɪŋ ɪt - ðə pɹɑsɛs wɑz ɪɹɪvɝsəbəl.

The incredible abilities came at a cost, however, for the rings leeched life from their hosts, killing them in a matter of days. Removing the ring would slow that process slightly, but once activated -  done by touching a drop of one's own blood to the stone ring while wearing it - the process was irreversible.

ðiz faɪv wəd nɑt ɹɪtɝn. ðeɪ wəd steɪ bɪhaɪnd, wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɹɪzʌls ə ðə ɹeɪd, tə kɪl əz mɛni mɛɹəθdəmeɪn əz ðeɪ kʊd. ɪt wɑz ə tɛɹəbəl weɪst - ðoʊz deɪmeɪn ʃəd bi liʃt - bʌt bɛɾɝ tə kɪl əm ðən liv əm ɪn ðə hænz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

These five would not return. They would stay behind, whatever the results of the raid, to kill as many marath'damane as they could. It was a terrible waste - those damane should be leashed - but better to kill them than leave them in the hands of the Dragon Reborn.

fɔɹtwoʊnə muv tə ðə nɛkst soʊlʒɝ ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt laɪn, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ðə kɪs ən ðə blɛsɪŋ.

Fortuona moved to the next soldier in the short line, giving him the kiss and the blessing.

soʊ mʌtʃ hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ðə deɪz sɪns əɹ miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hɝ nu neɪm wɑz oʊnli wʌn ə ðə mænəfɛsteɪʃənz. naʊ ivən ðə haɪ blʌɾ ɔfən pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz bɪfɔɹ hɝ. hɝ sɔɪhɪn - sɪlutʃə ɪnkluɾəd - hæd ʃeɪv ðə hɛɹ fɹəm ðɛɹ hɛdz. fɹəm naʊ ɑn, ðeɪ wəd liv ðə ɹaɪt saɪɾ ə ðɛɹ hɛdz ʃeɪvd ən ɡɹoʊ hɛɹ daʊn ðə lɛf saɪd, bɹeɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ əz ɪt ɡɹu. fəɹ naʊ, ðeɪ wɔɹ kæps ɑn ðə lɛft.

So much had changed in the days since her meeting with the Dragon Reborn. Her new name was only one of the manifestations. Now even the High Blood often prostrated themselves before her. Her so'jhin - Selucia included - had shaved the hair from their heads. From now on, they would leave the right side of their heads shaved and grow hair down the left side, braiding it as it grew. For now, they wore caps on the left.

ðə kɑmən pipəl wɔk mɔɹ kɑnfəɾəntli, mɔɹ pɹaʊdli. ðeɪ hæɾ ən ɛmpɹɛs əɡɛn. wɪð ɔl ðət wɑz ɹɔŋ ɪn ðə wɝld, ðɪs wʌn θɪŋ wɑz ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn.

The common people walked more confidently, more proudly. They had an empress again. With all that was wrong in the world, this one thing was right again.

fɔɹtwoʊnə kɪs ðə læst ə ðə faɪv blʌdnaɪvz, spikɪŋ ðə wɝdz kəndɛmɪŋ əm tə dɛθ, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ tə hɛɹoʊɪzəm. ʃi stɛp bæk, sɪlutʃə stændɪŋ əɾ əɹ saɪd. dʒɛnɝəl julən keɪm fɔɹwɝɾ ən baʊd hɪmsɛlf loʊ. "lɛɾ ɪt bi noʊn baɪ ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, ðət wi ʃæl nɑt feɪl hɝ."

Fortuona kissed the last of the five Bloodknives, speaking the words condemning them to death, but also to heroism. She stepped back, Selucia standing at her side. General Yulan came forward and bowed himself low. "Let it be known by the Empress, may she live forever, that we shall not fail her."

"ɪɾ ɪz noʊn," sɪlutʃə sɛd. "laɪt fɑloʊ ju. noʊ ðəɾ əɹ mædʒəsti, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, sɔ ə nu spɹɪŋ ɹoʊz dʒɹɑp θɹi pɛɾəlz ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾən tədeɪ. ði oʊmən ə jəɹ vɪktɝi hæz bɪn ɡɪvən.

"It is known," Selucia said. "Light follow you. Know that Her Majesty, may she live forever, saw a new spring rose drop three petals in the garden today. The omen of your victory has been given.

fʊlfɪl ɪt, dʒɛnɝəl, ən jəɹ ɹɪwɔɹd ʃæl bi ɡɹeɪt."

Fulfill it, General, and your reward shall be great."

julən stʊd, səluɾɪŋ, fɪs tə bɹɛst, mɛɾəl snæpɪŋ əɡɛns mɛɾəl. hi lɛd ðə soʊlʒɝz tə ðə tɔɹeɪkən pɛnz, ðə faɪv blʌdnaɪvz fɝst. wɪðɪn moʊməns, ðə fɝs kɹitʃɝ ɹæn daʊn ə lɔŋ pæstʃɝ aʊtsaɪd ðə bæk ə ðə pɛn, mɑɹkt wɪð poʊlz ən stʃɹimɝz, ðən lɔntʃt ɪtsɛlf ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ʌðɝz fɑloʊd, ə flit, mɔɹ ðən fɔɹtwoʊnə hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɪn ðə skaɪ ət wʌns. əz ðə faɪnəl laɪɾ ə sʌnsɛt daɪd, ðeɪ stʃɹʌk nɔɹθwɝd.

Yulan stood, saluting, fist to breast, metal snapping against metal. He led the soldiers to the to'raken pens, the five Bloodknives first. Within moments, the first creature ran down a long pasture outside the back of the pen, marked with poles and streamers, then launched itself into the air. Others followed, a fleet, more than Fortuona had ever seen in the sky at once. As the final light of sunset died, they struck northward.

ɹeɪkən ən tɔɹeɪkən wɝ nɑt nɔɹməli juzd ɪn ðɪs mænɝ. moʊst ɹeɪdz wəd bi əkɑmplɪʃt baɪ dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz ɔf əɾ ə steɪdʒɪŋ pɔɪnt, wɛɹ ðə tɔɹeɪkən wəd weɪt waɪl ðə soʊlʒɝz ətækt ən ɹɪtɝnd. bʌt ðɪs ɹeɪd wɑz tu vaɪɾəl. julənz plæn kɔl fəɹ ə mɔɹ dɛɹɪŋ əsɔlt, ðə laɪks ʌv wɪtʃ hæd ɹɛɹli bɪn kɑntəmpleɪɾɪd. tɔɹeɪkən wɪð deɪmeɪn ən sʌldəm ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, ətækɪŋ fɹəm ði ɛɹ. ɪt kəd bi ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʌv ə boʊl nu tæktɪk. əɹ ɪt kəd lid tə ə dɪzæstɝ.

Raken and to'raken were not normally used in this manner. Most raids would be accomplished by dropping the soldiers off at a staging point, where the to'raken would wait while the soldiers attacked and returned. But this raid was too vital. Yulan's plan called for a more daring assault, the likes of which had rarely been contemplated. To'raken with damane and sul'dam on their backs, attacking from the air. It could be the beginning of a bold new tactic. Or it could lead to a disaster.

"wi hæv tʃeɪnʒd ɛvɹiθɪŋ," fɔɹtwoʊnə sɛd sɔfli. "dʒɛnɝəl ɡælɡən ɪz ɹɔŋ; ðɪs wɪl nɑt ɡɪv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ə wɝs bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ pəzɪʃən. ɪɾəl tɝn ɪm əɡɛnst ʌs."

"We have changed everything," Fortuona said softly. "General Galgan is wrong; this will not give the Dragon Reborn a worse bargaining position. It will turn him against us."

"ænd wɑz i nɑɾ əɡɛnst əs bɪfɔɹ?" sɪlutʃə æskt.

"And was he not against us before?" Selucia asked.

"noʊ," fɔɹtwoʊnə sɛd. "wi wɝ əɡɛns hɪm."

"No," Fortuona said. "We were against him."

"æn ðəɹ ɪz ə dɪfɝəns?"

"And there is a difference?"

"jɛs," fɔɹtwoʊnə sɛd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə klaʊɾ ə tɔɹeɪkən, dʒʌs bɛɹli vɪzəbəl ɪn ðə skaɪ. "ðɛɹ ɪz. aɪ fɪɹ wi ʃæl sun si dʒʌs haʊ bɪɡ ə dɪfɝəns ðəɾ ɪz."
