"Yes," Fortuona said, watching the cloud of to'raken, just barely visible in the sky. "There is. I fear we shall soon see just how big a difference that is."

tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɛvən

CHAPTER 37

eɪ fɔɹs ə laɪt mɪn sæt kwaɪətli, wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd dʒɹɛs. hɪz moʊʃənz wɝ tɛns ən kɛɹfəl, laɪk ðə stɛps ʌv ə pɝfɔɹmɝ wɔkɪŋ ðə haɪ ɹoʊp əɾ ə mənædʒɝi. hi dɪɾ ʌp ðə lɛf kʌf ɑn ɪz kɹɪsp waɪt ʃɝt wɪð sloʊ, dɪlɪbɝɪt fɪŋɡɝz. ðə ɹaɪt kʌf wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi dʌn ʌp; hɪz sɝvəns sɔ tə ðæt.

A Force of Light Min sat quietly, watching Rand dress. His motions were tense and careful, like the steps of a performer walking the high rope at a menagerie. He did up the left cuff on his crisp white shirt with slow, deliberate fingers. The right cuff was already done up; his servants saw to that.

ɪt wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ivnɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. nɑt kwaɪt dɑɹk jɛt, ðoʊ ðə ʃʌɾɝz wɝ kloʊzd ɪn pɹɛpɝeɪʃən. ɹænd ɹitʃt fəɹ ə ɡoʊld ən blæk koʊt, slaɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn sliv, ðən ði ʌðɝ. ðən dɪd ðə bʌɾənz wʌn æftɝ ənʌðɝ. hi hæd noʊ tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ðiz; hi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ pɹæktəst ət wɝkɪŋ wɪð oʊnli wʌn hænd. bʌɾən æftɝ bʌɾən. fɝst, sɛkənd, θɝd, fɔɹθ. . . .

It was approaching evening outside. Not quite dark yet, though the shutters were closed in preparation. Rand reached for a gold and black coat, sliding on one sleeve, then the other. Then did the buttons one after another. He had no trouble with these; he was growing practiced at working with only one hand. Button after button. First, second, third, fourth. . . .

mɪn fɛlt laɪk skɹimɪŋ.

Min felt like screaming.

"du jə wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt?" ʃi æskt.

"Do you want to talk about it?" she asked.

ɹænd dɪd nɑt tɝn fɹəm ðə mɪɹɝ. "əbaʊt wʌt?"

Rand did not turn from the mirror. "About what?"

"ðə sintʃæn."

"The Seanchan."

"ðɛɹ wɪl bi noʊ pis," hi sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ɪz koʊt kɑlɝ. "aɪ hæv feɪld." hɪz toʊn wɑz ɪmoʊʃənləs, jɛt sʌmhaʊ tɔt.

"There will be no peace," he said, straightening his coat collar. "I have failed." His tone was emotionless, yet somehow taut.

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt tə bi fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd, ɹænd."

"It's all right to be frustrated, Rand."

"fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ɪz pɔɪnləs," hi sɛd. "æŋɡɝ ɪz pɔɪnləs. niðɝ ɪmoʊʃən wɪl tʃeɪnʒ fæks, ən ðə fækt ɪz ðəɾ aɪ hæv noʊ mɔɹ taɪm tə weɪst ɑn ðə sintʃæn. wɪl əv tə ɹɪsk ən ətæk fɹəm bɪhaɪn baɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə læs bæɾəl wɪθaʊt stəbɪlɪɾi ɪn ɑɹæd dumən. ɪts nɑɾ aɪdil, bʌɾ ɪts wʌt mʌs hæpən."

"Frustration is pointless," he said. "Anger is pointless. Neither emotion will change facts, and the fact is that I have no more time to waste on the Seanchan. We will have to risk an attack from behind by riding to the Last Battle without stability in Arad Doman. It is not ideal, but it is what must happen."

ði ɛɹ ʃɪmɝɾ əbʌv ɹænd, ən ə maʊntən əpɪɹd ðɛɹ. vjuɪŋz wɝ soʊ kɑmən ɝaʊn ɹænd ðət mɪn juʒəwəli fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə ɪɡnɔɹ əm ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ nu - ðoʊ ʃi dɪd spɛn taɪm səm deɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɪk əm ɔl aʊɾ ən sɔɹt θɹu ðɛm. ðɪs wʌn wɑz nu, ən ɪt kɑɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən. ðə taʊɝɪŋ maʊntən wɑz blæstəɾ aʊɾ ɑn wʌn saɪd, meɪkɪŋ ə dʒæɡd hoʊl daʊn ðə sloʊp. dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt? ɪt wɑz kloʊkt ɪn dɑɹk ʃædoʊz, əz ɪf ʃeɪɾɪd baɪ klaʊdz haɪ əbʌv. ðət wɑz ɑd; wɛnɛvɝ ʃid sin ðə maʊntən, ɪt hæd ɹitʃt haɪɝ ðən ðə klaʊdz ðɛmsɛlvz.

The air shimmered above Rand, and a mountain appeared there. Viewings were so common around Rand that Min usually forced herself to ignore them unless they were new - though she did spend time some days trying to pick them all out and sort through them. This one was new, and it caught her attention. The towering mountain was blasted out on one side, making a jagged hole down the slope. Dragonmount? It was cloaked in dark shadows, as if shaded by clouds high above. That was odd; whenever she'd seen the mountain, it had reached higher than the clouds themselves.

dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn ɪn ʃædoʊz. ɪt wəd bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ɹænd ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ. wɑz ðəɾ ə taɪni pɹɪk ə laɪt ʃaɪnɪŋ fɹəm ðə hɛvənz daʊn ɑntu ðə pɔɪn ə ðə maʊntən?

Dragonmount in shadows. It would be important to Rand in the future. Was that a tiny prick of light shining from the heavens down onto the point of the mountain?

ðə vjuɪŋ vænɪʃt. ðoʊ mɪn nu wʌt səm ə ðɛm mɛnt, ðɪs wʌn bæfəl hɝ. ʃi saɪd, linɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə ɹɛd-kʊʃən tʃɛɹ. hɝ bʊks leɪ skæɾɝd ɑn ðə flɔɹ; ʃid bɪn dɛɾɪkeɪtɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ taɪm tə hɝ stʌɾiz, pɑɹtli kəz ʃi fɛlt ɹændz sɛns ə ɝdʒənsi, ən pɑɹtli kəz ʃi dɪdnt noʊ wʌɾ ɛls tə du. ʃi laɪk tə θɪŋk ðət ʃi wɑz keɪpəbəl ə teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ə hɝsɛlf. ən ʃid bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk ə hɝsɛlf əz ə læs dɪfɛns fəɹ ɹænd.

The viewing vanished. Though Min knew what some of them meant, this one baffled her. She sighed, leaning back in the red-cushioned chair. Her books lay scattered on the floor; she'd been dedicating more and more time to her studies, partly because she felt Rand's sense of urgency, and partly because she didn't know what else to do. She liked to think that she was capable of taking care of herself. And she'd begun to think of herself as a last defense for Rand.

mɪn hæd dɪskʌvɝd dʒʌs haʊ jusfəl ʃi wɑz əz ə "laɪn ə dɪfɛns." ʃid bɪn əbaʊɾ əz jusfəl əz ə tʃaɪld! ɪn fækt, ʃid bɪn ə hɪnʒɹəns, ə tul fəɹ sɛmɝhɪdʒ tə juz əɡɛns hɪm. ʃid bɪn ɪndɪɡnənt wən ɹænd hæd sədʒɛstəd sɛndɪŋ əɹ əweɪ, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ə tʌŋ-læʃɪŋ fəɹ ivən sədʒɛstɪŋ ɪt. sɛn əɹ əweɪ! tə kip əɹ seɪf? ðət wɑz fulɪʃnəs! ʃi kəd teɪk kɛɹ ə hɝsɛlf.

Min had discovered just how useful she was as a "line of defense." She'd been about as useful as a child! In fact, she'd been a hindrance, a tool for Semirhage to use against him. She'd been indignant when Rand had suggested sending her away, giving him a tongue-lashing for even suggesting it. Send her away! To keep her safe? That was foolishness! She could take care of herself.

soʊ ʃi hæd θɔt. naʊ ʃi sɔ ðət hid bɪn ɹaɪt.

So she had thought. Now she saw that he'd been right.

ðət meɪɾ əɹ sɪk. soʊ ʃi stʌɾid ən tʃɹaɪd tə steɪ aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ. hid tʃeɪnʒd ɑn ðət deɪ, əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ bɹaɪt hæd tɝn ɔf ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm. ə læmp flɪkɝɪŋ aʊt, ɪts ɔɪl ɡɔn, livɪŋ oʊnli ðə keɪsɪŋ. hi lʊkt əɾ əɹ dɪfɹənli, naʊ. wən ðoʊz aɪz ə hɪz stʌɾid hɝ, dɪd ðeɪ si oʊnli ə laɪəbɪlɪɾi?

That made her sick. So she studied and tried to stay out of his way. He'd changed on that day, as if something bright had turned off inside of him. A lamp flickering out, its oil gone, leaving only the casing. He looked at her differently, now. When those eyes of his studied her, did they see only a liability?

ʃi ʃɪvɝd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃʌv ðət θɔt fɹəm əɹ maɪnd.

She shivered, trying to shove that thought from her mind.

ɹænd pʊɾ ɑn ɪz buts, ðən dɪɾ ʌp ðɛɹ bʌkəlz.

Rand put on his boots, then did up their buckles.

hi stʊd, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə sɔɹd wɪtʃ lin əɡɛnst ɪz kloʊðɪŋ tʃɛst. ðə blæk skæbɝd, wɪð ɪts lækɝd ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən, spɑɹkəld ɪn ðə laɪt. sətʃ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ wɛpən ðoʊz skɑlɝz hæd faʊn bɪniθ ðə səbmɝdʒ stætʃu. ðə sɔɹd fɛl soʊ oʊld. wɑz ɹænd wɛɹɪŋ ɪt tədeɪ əz ə sɪmbəl ə sʌmθɪŋ? ə saɪn, pɝhæps, ðəɾ i wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə bæɾəl?

He stood, reaching for the sword which leaned against his clothing chest. The black scabbard, with its lacquered red and gold dragon, sparkled in the light. Such a strange weapon those scholars had found beneath the submerged statue. The sword felt so old. Was Rand wearing it today as a symbol of something? A sign, perhaps, that he was riding to battle?

"jɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ æftɝ hɝ, ɑɹən ju?" mɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf æskɪŋ. "ɡɹeɪndəl."

"You're going after her, aren't you?" Min found herself asking. "Graendal."

"aɪ hæv tə fɪks wʌt pɹɑbləmz aɪ kæn," ɹænd sɛd, pʊlɪŋ ði eɪntʃən sɔɹd fɹəm ðə ʃiθ ən tʃɛkɪŋ ðə bleɪd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɛɹən mɑɹk, bʌt ðə faɪn stil bleɪd ɡlɪsən ɪn ðə læmplaɪt, ʃoʊɪŋ ði ʌnʒəleɪtɪŋ laɪnz ʌv ɪts foʊldəd mɛɾəl. ɪt hæd bɪn paʊɝ-fɔɹdʒd, hi kleɪmd. hi sim tə noʊ θɪŋz əbaʊɾ ɪɾ i dɪd nɑt ʃɛɹ.

"I have to fix what problems I can," Rand said, pulling the ancient sword from the sheath and checking the blade. There was no heron mark, but the fine steel blade glistened in the lamplight, showing the undulating lines of its folded metal. It had been Power-forged, he claimed. He seemed to know things about it he did not share.

ɹænd snæp ðə bleɪɾ ɪndə ðə blæk skæbɝd, lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. "fɪks ðə pɹɑbləmz jə kæn, doʊn fɹɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə wʌnz jə kænɑt. ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tæm wʌns toʊl mi. ɑɹæd dumən wɪl əv tə sɝvaɪv əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn ɑn ɪts oʊn. ðə læs θɪŋ aɪ kən də fəɹ ðə pipəl hɪɹ ɪz ɹimuv wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən fɹəm ðɛɹ sɔɪl."

Rand snapped the blade into the black scabbard, looking at her. "Fix the problems you can, don't fret over the ones you cannot. It was something Tam once told me. Arad Doman will have to survive against the Seanchan on its own. The last thing I can do for the people here is remove one of the Forsaken from their soil."

"ʃi maɪt bi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ju, ɹænd," mɪn sɛd. "dɪɾ ɪɾ əkɝ tə jə ðət ðə bɔɪ nɪneɪiv faʊnd wɑz ə plænt? ɪntɛndəd tə bi dɪskʌvɝd, tə lid jə ɪndə ə tʃɹæp?"

"She might be waiting for you, Rand," Min said. "Did it occur to you that the boy Nynaeve found was a plant? Intended to be discovered, to lead you into a trap?"

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "hi wɑz dʒɛnjəwən, mɪn. mɑɡiɾin maɪɾ əv kənsɪɾɝd ə tʃɹɪk laɪk ðæt, bʌt nɑt ɡɹeɪndəl. ʃid bi tu wɝiɾ əbaʊt biɪŋ tʃɹeɪst. wɪv tə muv kwɪkli, bɪfɔɹ wɝd ɹitʃəz əɹ ðət ʃiz bɪn kɑmpɹəmaɪzd. aɪ mʌst stʃɹaɪk naʊ."

He hesitated, then shook his head. "He was genuine, Min. Moghedien might have considered a trick like that, but not Graendal. She'd be too worried about being traced. We have to move quickly, before word reaches her that she has been compromised. I must strike now."

mɪn stʊd.

Min stood.

"ɑɹ jə kʌmɪŋ, ðɛn?" ɹænd æskt, lʊkɪŋ sɝpɹaɪzd.

"Are you coming, then?" Rand asked, looking surprised.

ʃi flʌʃt. wʌɾ ɪf θɪŋz ɡoʊ əz pʊɹli wɪð ɡɹeɪndəl əz ðeɪ dɪd wɪð sɛmɝhɪdʒ? wʌɾ ɪf aɪ bɪkʌm ə tul əɡɛnst ɪm əɡɛn?

She flushed. What if things go as poorly with Graendal as they did with Semirhage? What if I become a tool against him again?

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd, dʒʌs tə pɹuv tə hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi wɑznt ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp. "ʌv kɔɹs aɪm kʌmɪŋ. doʊn θɪŋk jə kən liv mi bɪhaɪnd!"

"Yes," she said, just to prove to herself that she wasn't giving up. "Of course I'm coming. Don't think you can leave me behind!"

"aɪ wʊdn dʒɹim ʌv ɪt," hi sɛd flætli. "kʌm."

"I wouldn't dream of it," he said flatly. "Come."

ʃiɾ ɪkspɛktəd mɔɹ ʌv ən ɑɹɡjəmənt.

She'd expected more of an argument.

fɹəm ðə naɪt stæn i pɪkt ʌp ðə stætʃuɛɾ ʌv ə mæn hoʊldɪŋ əlɔft ə ɡloʊb. hi tɝn ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn ɪz hænd, ɪnspɛktɪŋ ɪt, ðən lʊkt ʌp ət mɪn, əz ɪf ɪn tʃælənʒ. ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

From the night stand he picked up the statuette of a man holding aloft a globe. He turned the ter'angreal in his hand, inspecting it, then looked up at Min, as if in challenge. She said nothing.

hi tʌk ðə stætʃuɛɾ ɪndə ði oʊvɝsaɪz pɑkəɾ ə hɪz koʊt, ðən stʃɹoʊd fɹəm ðə ɹum, eɪntʃənt, paʊɝ-fɔɹdʒ sɔɹd bɛltəd tə hɪz weɪst.

He tucked the statuette into the oversized pocket of his coat, then strode from the room, ancient, Power-forged sword belted to his waist.

mɪn hɝiɾ æftɝ ɹænd. hi ɡlænst ət ðə pɛɹ ə meɪɾənz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə dɔɹ. "aɪ ɡoʊ tə bæɾəl," hi sɛd tə ðɛm. "bɹɪŋ noʊ mɔɹ ðən twɛnti."

Min hurried after Rand. He glanced at the pair of Maidens guarding the door. "I go to battle," he said to them. "Bring no more than twenty."

ðə meɪɾənz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə bɹif moʊmən ə hæntɔk; ðən wʌn loʊpt əhɛɾ ən ði ʌðɝ teɪld ɹænd əz i mɑɹtʃt daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. mɪn hɝiɾ ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm, hɑɹt θʌmpɪŋ, hɝ buts laʊɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz. hi hæd ɹʌʃt ɔf laɪk ðɪs tə faɪt fɔɹseɪkən bɪfɔɹ, bʌt juʒəwəli hi tʊk mɔɹ taɪm tə plæn. hid mənuvɝd sɑmaɪl fəɹ mʌnθs bɪfɔɹ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əɾ ɪljən. hid hæd bɛɹli ə sɪŋɡəl deɪ tə dɪsaɪd wʌt də wɪð ɡɹeɪndəl!

The Maidens exchanged a brief moment of handtalk; then one loped ahead and the other tailed Rand as he marched down the hallway. Min hurried up beside him, heart thumping, her boots loud on the floorboards. He had rushed off like this to fight Forsaken before, but usually he took more time to plan. He'd maneuvered Sammael for months before striking at Illian. He'd had barely a single day to decide what do with Graendal!

mɪn tʃɛkt əɹ naɪvz, meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən ðeɪ wɝ sɪkjʊɹ ɪn əɹ slivz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə nɝvəs hæbət. ɹænd ɹitʃt ði ɛn ə ðə hɔlweɪ, ðən stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə stɛɹz, hɪz feɪs stɪl kɑm, hɪz stɛp kwɪk bʌt nɑt hɝid. jɛɾ i sim laɪk ə θʌndɝstɔɹm, kənteɪn ən ɹæpt ʌp, sʌmhaʊ baʊn ən tʃænəl təwɔɹɾ ə sɪŋɡəl ɡoʊl. haʊ ʃi wɪʃt hid dʒʌst ɪksploʊɾ ən luz ɪz tɛmpɝ, ðə weɪ hi juz tə! hiɾ ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd əɹ ðɛn, bʌt hid nɛvɝ fɹaɪɾənd hɝ. nɑɾ əz i dɪd naʊ, wɪð ðoʊz aɪsi aɪz ʃi kʊdn ɹid, ðəɾ ɔɹə ʌv deɪnʒɝ. sɪns ði ɪnsəɾənt wɪð sɛmɝhɪdʒ, hi spoʊk ə duɪŋ "wʌtɛvɝ i hæd tə" ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə kɑst, ən ʃi nu ðəɾ i mʌst sið ət hævɪŋ feɪl tə kənvɪns ðə sintʃæn tə əlaɪ wɪð hɪm. wʌt wəd ðət kɑmbəneɪʃən ə feɪljɝ ən dɪtɝməneɪʃən lɛɾ ɪm tə du?

Min checked her knives, making certain they were secure in her sleeves, but it was just a nervous habit. Rand reached the end of the hallway, then strode down the stairs, his face still calm, his step quick but not hurried. Yet he seemed like a thunderstorm, contained and wrapped up, somehow bound and channeled toward a single goal. How she wished he'd just explode and lose his temper, the way he used to! He'd exasperated her then, but he'd never frightened her. Not as he did now, with those icy eyes she couldn't read, that aura of danger. Since the incident with Semirhage, he spoke of doing "whatever he had to" regardless of cost, and she knew that he must seethe at having failed to convince the Seanchan to ally with him. What would that combination of failure and determination lead him to do?

ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə waɪd stɛɹkeɪs, ɹænd spoʊk tə ə sɝvənt. "fɛtʃ fəɹ mi nɪneɪiv sədaɪ ən lɔɹd ɹæmʃələn. bɹɪŋ əm tə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum."

At the bottom of the wide staircase, Rand spoke to a servant. "Fetch for me Nynaeve Sedai and Lord Ramshalan. Bring them to the sitting room."

lɔɹd ɹæmʃələn? ði oʊvɝstʌf mæn fɹəm leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝz fɔɹmɝ sɝkəl? "ɹænd," mɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, ɹitʃɪŋ ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə stɛɹz, "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə plænɪŋ?"

Lord Ramshalan? The overstuffed man from Lady Chadmar's former circle? "Rand," Min said quietly, reaching the bottom of the stairs, "what are you planning?"

hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ. hi stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðə waɪt mɑɹbəl ɛntʃɹɪweɪ, ɛntɝɪŋ ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, wɪtʃ wɑz dɛkɝeɪɾəd ɪn dip ɹɛdz tə kəntʃɹæst wɪð ðə waɪt flɔɹ. hi dɪd nɑt sɪt, bʌt ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə mæp ʌv ɑɹæd dumən hiɾ ɔɹɾɝd pleɪst ɑn ðə wɔl. ði eɪdʒɪd mæp hʌŋ wɛɹ ə faɪn ɔɪl peɪntɪŋ wʌns hæd, ən sim kəmplitli aʊɾ ə pleɪs ɪn ðə ɹum.

He said nothing. He strode through the white marble entryway, entering the sitting room, which was decorated in deep reds to contrast with the white floor. He did not sit, but remained standing with his arms behind his back, studying the map of Arad Doman he'd ordered placed on the wall. The aged map hung where a fine oil painting once had, and seemed completely out of place in the room.

ɑn ðə mæp, ðəɹ wɑz ə blæk ɪŋk mɑɹk ət ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə smɔl leɪk tə ðə saʊθist. ɹænd hæd pleɪst ɪt ðəɹ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ æftɝ kɝb daɪd. ɪt mɑɹk nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ.

On the map, there was a black ink mark at the edge of a small lake to the southeast. Rand had placed it there the morning after Kerb died. It marked Natrin's Barrow.

"ɪt wɑz ə fɔɹt, wʌns," ɹænd sɛɾ æbsənli.

"It was a fort, once," Rand said absently.

"ðə sɪɾi wɛɹ ɡɹeɪndəl ɪz haɪɾɪŋ?" mɪn sɛd, wɔkɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm.

"The city where Graendal is hiding?" Min said, walking up beside him.

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪts nɑɾ ə sɪɾi. aɪv sɛn skaʊts. ɪts dʒʌst ə sɑlətɛɹi stʃɹʌktʃɝ, bɪlt lɔŋ əɡoʊ tə wɑtʃ ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst ən ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛnst ɪnkɝʒən θɹu ðə pæsəz baɪ meɪnɛðɝən. ɪt hæzən bɪn juz fəɹ mɪlətɛɹi pɝpəsəz sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz; ðɛɹz hɑɹdli nid tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪnveɪʒən fɹəm tu ɹɪvɝz pipəl u doʊn ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə neɪm meɪnɛðɝən."

He shook his head. "It's not a city. I've sent scouts. It's just a solitary structure, built long ago to watch the Mountains of Mist and guard against incursion through the passes by Manetheren. It hasn't been used for military purposes since the Trolloc Wars; there's hardly need to worry about invasion from Two Rivers people who don't even remember the name Manetheren."

mɪn nɑɾəd. "ðoʊ, ɑɹæd dumən dɪd ɡɛɾ ɪnveɪɾəd baɪ ə ʃɛpɝd fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

Min nodded. "Though, Arad Doman did get invaded by a shepherd from the Two Rivers."

wʌns ðət wʊɾə meɪɾ ɪm smaɪl. ʃi kɛp fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ðəɾ i dɪdn də ðəɾ ɛnimɔɹ.

Once that would have made him smile. She kept forgetting that he didn't do that anymore.

"ə fju sɛntʃɝiz bæk," ɹænd sɛd, aɪz nɛɹoʊɾ ɪn θɔt, "ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɑɹæd dumən siz nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ bæk ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə θɹoʊn. fəɹ səm taɪm bɪfɔɹ, ɪt hæd bɪn ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ ə maɪnɝ noʊbəl fæmli fɹəm toʊmən hɛɾ u hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɛɾ ʌp ðɛɹ oʊn nu kɪŋdəm. ðət hæpənz ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn əkeɪʒənəli. ðə dəmɑni kɪŋ laɪk ðə loʊkeɪʃən, ən juz ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs əz ə pæləs ɪnstɛd.

"A few centuries back," Rand said, eyes narrowed in thought, "the king of Arad Doman seized Natrin's Barrow back in the name of the throne. For some time before, it had been occupied by a minor noble family from Toman Head who had been trying to set up their own new kingdom. That happens on Almoth Plain occasionally. The Domani king liked the location, and used the fortress as a palace instead.

"hi spɛn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm ðɛɹ, soʊ mʌtʃ, ɪn fækt, ðət sɛvɹəl ə hɪz mɝtʃən ɛnəmiz ɡeɪn tu mʌtʃ paʊɝ ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən. ðə kɪŋ fɛl, bʌɾ ɪz səksɛsɝz ɔlsoʊ juz ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs, ən ɪt bɪkeɪm ə pɑpjəlɝ ɹitʃɹit fəɹ ðə kɹaʊn wən ðə kɪŋ niɾəd ɹilækseɪʃən. ðə pɹæktəs dwɪndəl dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɹ soʊ, əntɪl ɪt wɑz ɡɹæntəd tə ə dɪstən kʌzən ə ðə kɪŋ əbaʊt fɪfti jɪɹz bæk. ðɛɹ fæmli hæz juzd ɪɾ ɛvɝ sɪns. əmʌŋ ðə dʒɛnɝəl dəmɑni pɑpjələs, nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ hæz bɪn lɑɹdʒli fɝɡɑɾən."

"He spent a great deal of time there, so much, in fact, that several of his merchant enemies gained too much power in Bandar Eban. The King fell, but his successors also used the fortress, and it became a popular retreat for the Crown when the King needed relaxation. The practice dwindled during the last hundred years or so, until it was granted to a distant cousin of the King about fifty years back. Their family has used it ever since. Among the general Domani populace, Natrin's Barrow has been largely forgotten."

"ɪksɛp baɪ ælsələm?" mɪn æskt.

"Except by Alsalam?" Min asked.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ. aɪ daʊɾ i nu ʌv ɪɾ əɾ ɔl. aɪ lɝn ðɪs hɪstɝi fɹəm ðə ɹɔɪəl ɑɹkəvɪst, hu hæd tə sɝtʃ fəɹ aʊɝz tə loʊkeɪt ðə neɪm ə ðə fæmli juzɪŋ ðə pleɪs. ðəɹ əz bɪn noʊ kɑntækt wɪð əm fəɹ mʌnθs, ðoʊ ðeɪ juz tə vɪzət taʊnz ɑn əkeɪʒən. ðə fju fɑɹmstɛɾɝz ɪn ði ɛɹiə seɪ ðət sʌmwʌn nu simz tə bi lɪvɪŋ ɪn ðə pæləs, ðoʊ noʊbɑdi noʊz wɛɹ ðə fɔɹmɝ oʊnɝ wɛnt. ðeɪ sim sɝpɹaɪz ðət ðeɪv nɛvɝ θɔɾ əbaʊt haʊ ɑd ðəɾ ɪz."

Rand shook his head. "No. I doubt he knew of it at all. I learned this history from the royal archivist, who had to search for hours to locate the name of the family using the place. There has been no contact with them for months, though they used to visit towns on occasion. The few farmsteaders in the area say that someone new seems to be living in the palace, though nobody knows where the former owner went. They seem surprised that they've never thought about how odd that is."

hi aɪd hɝ. "ðɪs ɪz ɪɡzækli ðə sɔɹɾ ə loʊkeɪʃən ɡɹeɪndəl wəd tʃuz əz əɹ sɛntɝ ə paʊɝ.

He eyed her. "This is exactly the sort of location Graendal would choose as her center of power.

ɪts ə dʒuəl - ə fɝɡɑɾən fɔɹtʃɹəs ə bjuɾi ən paʊɝ, eɪntʃən ən ɹiɡəl. kloʊs ɪnʌf tə bændɑɹ ɛbən fəɹ əɹ tə hæv ə hæn ɪn ɹulɪŋ ɑɹæd dumən, bʌt fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ tə bi dɪfɛnsəbəl ən sɪkluɾɪd. aɪ meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk ɪn maɪ sɝtʃɪz fəɹ əɹ - aɪ əsumd ʃid wɑn ə bjuɾəfəl mænɝ wɪð ɡɑɹɾənz ən ɡɹaʊnz. aɪ ʃəɾ əv ɹilaɪzd; ɪɾ ɪzən dʒʌs bjuɾi ðət ʃi kəlɛks, bʌt pɹɛstiʒ. ə mæɡnɪfəsən fɔɹtʃɹəs fəɹ kɪŋz fɪts əɹ dʒʌst əz mʌtʃ əz ən ɛləɡən mænɝ haʊs. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sɪns ðɪs wʌn ɪz mɔɹ pæləs ðən fɔɹt naʊ."

It's a jewel - a forgotten fortress of beauty and power, ancient and regal. Close enough to Bandar Eban for her to have a hand in ruling Arad Doman, but far enough away to be defensible and secluded. I made a mistake in my searches for her - I assumed she'd want a beautiful manor with gardens and grounds. I should have realized; it isn't just beauty that she collects, but prestige. A magnificent fortress for kings fits her just as much as an elegant manor house. Particularly since this one is more palace than fort now."

fʊtstɛps ɪn ði ɛntʃɹɪweɪ bɪhaɪn dʒɹu mɪnz ətɛnʃən, ən ə fju sɛkənz leɪɾɝ ə sɝvən ʌʃɝɾ ɪn nɪneɪiv ən ðə fɑpɪʃ ɹæmʃələn, wɪð ɪz pɔɪntəd bɪɹɾ ən θɪn mʌstæʃ. tədeɪ hi hæd taɪni bɛlz ət ði ɛn ə ðə bɪɹɾ ən wɔɹ ə blæk vɛlvət bjuɾi mɑɹk ɑn ɪz tʃik, ɔlsoʊ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə bɛl. hi wɔɹ ə lus sɪlk kɑstum ʌv ɡɹin ən blu, ðə slivz dʒɹupɪŋ, ɹʌfəld ʃɝt poʊkɪŋ aʊt bɪniθ. mɪn dɪdn kɛɹ wʌt fæʃən dɪkteɪɾəd, ðə mæn lʊkt ɹɪdɪkjələs. laɪk ə dɪʃɛvəl pikɑk.

Footsteps in the entryway behind drew Min's attention, and a few seconds later a servant ushered in Nynaeve and the foppish Ramshalan, with his pointed beard and thin mustache. Today he had tiny bells at the end of the beard and wore a black velvet beauty mark on his cheek, also in the shape of a bell. He wore a loose silk costume of green and blue, the sleeves drooping, ruffled shirt poking out beneath. Min didn't care what fashion dictated, the man looked ridiculous. Like a disheveled peacock.

"maɪ lɔɹd kɔl fəɹ mi?" ɹæmʃələn sɛd, boʊɪŋ ɛkstʃɹævəɡənli təwɔɹd ɹænd.

"My Lord called for me?" Ramshalan said, bowing extravagantly toward Rand.

ɹænd dɪdn tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə mæp. "aɪ hæv ə pʌzəl fəɹ ju, ɹæmʃələn," hi sɛd. "aɪ wɑnə noʊ wʌt jə θɪŋk."

Rand didn't turn away from the map. "I have a puzzle for you, Ramshalan," he said. "I want to know what you think."

"pliz, doʊn hɛzəteɪt, maɪ lɔɹd!"

"Please, don't hesitate, my Lord!"

"ðɛn tɛl mi ðɪs: haʊ də aɪ aʊθɪŋk ən ɛnəmi aɪ noʊ ɪz smɑɹɾɝ ðən aɪ æm?"

"Then tell me this: How do I outthink an enemy I know is smarter than I am?"

"maɪ lɔɹd." ɹæmʃələn baʊɾ ə sɛkən taɪm, əz ɪf wɝid ðət ɹænd hædnt noʊɾəst ðə fɝst wʌn.

"My Lord." Ramshalan bowed a second time, as if worried that Rand hadn't noticed the first one.

"ʃʊɹli jə sik tə tʃɹɪk mi! ðəɹ ɪz noʊbɑdi mɔɹ ɪntɛlədʒən ðən jɝsɛlf."

"Surely you seek to trick me! There is nobody more intelligent than yourself."

"aɪ wɪʃ ðət wɝ tʃɹu," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ feɪs səm ə ðə moʊs kɹæfti pipəl u hæv ɛvɝ lɪvd. maɪ kɝən foʊ ʌndɝstænz ðə maɪnz ʌv ʌðɝz ɪn ə weɪ ðəɾ aɪ kænɑt hoʊp tə mætʃ. soʊ haʊ də aɪ dɪfit hɝ? ʃɪl vænɪʃ ðə moʊmən aɪ θɹɛɾən hɝ, ɹʌnɪŋ tə wʌn ʌv ə dʌzən ʌðɝ ɹɛfjudʒɪz ʃiz ʃʊɹ tə hæv sɛɾ ʌp. ʃi woʊn faɪt mi hɛd-ɑn, jɛɾ ɪf aɪ dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɝ fɔɹtʃɹəs ɪn ə sɝpɹaɪz ətæk, aɪ ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ əɹ slɪp əweɪ ən nɛvɝ noʊɪŋ ɪf aɪv fɪnɪʃt hɝ."

"I wish that were true," Rand said softly. "I face some of the most crafty people who have ever lived. My current foe understands the minds of others in a way that I cannot hope to match. So how do I defeat her? She will vanish the moment I threaten her, running to one of a dozen other refuges she is sure to have set up. She won't fight me head-on, yet if I destroy her fortress in a surprise attack, I risk letting her slip away and never knowing if I've finished her."

"ə pɹɑbləm ɪndid, maɪ lɔɹd," ɹæmʃələn sɛd. hi lʊkt kənfjuzd.

"A problem indeed, my Lord," Ramshalan said. He looked confused.

ɹænd nɑɾəd, əz ɪf tə hɪmsɛlf. "aɪ hæv tə pɪɹ ɪndə hɝ aɪz, si ɪndə hɝ soʊl, ən noʊ ðəɾ ɪts əɹ ðəɾ aɪ feɪs ən nɑt səm dəkɔɪ. aɪ hæv tə də ðət wɪθaʊt fɹaɪɾənɪŋ əɹ ɪndə ɹʌnɪŋ. haʊ? haʊ kən aɪ kɪl ə foʊ hu ɪz mɔɹ klɛvɝ ðən maɪsɛlf, ə foʊ hu ɪz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə sɝpɹaɪz, jɛɾ u ɪz ɔlsoʊ ənwɪlɪŋ tə kənfɹʌn mi?"

Rand nodded, as if to himself. "I have to peer into her eyes, see into her soul, and know that it's her that I face and not some decoy. I have to do that without frightening her into running. How? How can I kill a foe who is more clever than myself, a foe who is impossible to surprise, yet who is also unwilling to confront me?"

ɹæmʃələn lʊkt oʊvɝwɛlm baɪ ðoʊz dɪmænz. "aɪ. . . . maɪ lɔɹd, ɪf jəɹ foʊ ɪz ðət klɛvɝ, ðən pɝhæps jəɹ bɛs kɔɹs ʌv ækʃən ɪz tə ɹɪkwɛs ði eɪɾ ə sʌmwʌn mɔɹ klɛvɝ?"

Ramshalan looked overwhelmed by those demands. "I. . . . My Lord, if your foe is that clever, then perhaps your best course of action is to request the aid of someone more clever?"

ɹænd tɝn tə hɪm. "æn ɛksələn sədʒɛstʃən, ɹæmʃələn. pɝhæps aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi dʌn dʒʌs ðæt."

Rand turned to him. "An excellent suggestion, Ramshalan. Perhaps I've already done just that."

ðə mæn swɛld. hi θɪŋks ðæts waɪ ɹænd sʌmən hɪm! mɪn ɹilaɪzd. ʃi hæd tə haɪɾ əɹ smaɪl wɪð ə tɝn ə ðə hɛɾ ən ə ɹeɪz hænd.

The man swelled. He thinks that's why Rand summoned him! Min realized. She had to hide her smile with a turn of the head and a raised hand.

" aɪ ɛf jə hæɾ ən ɛnəmi sətʃ əz ðɪs, ɹæmʃələn, wʌt wəd jə du?" ɹænd æskt. "aɪ ɡɹoʊ ɪmpeɪʃənt. ɡɪmi ən ænsɝ."

" I f you had an enemy such as this, Ramshalan, what would you do?" Rand asked. "I grow impatient. Give me an answer."

"aɪd meɪk ən əlaɪəns, maɪ lɔɹd," ɹæmʃələn sɛd wɪθaʊt pɔzɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ sɛkənd. "ɛniwʌn ðət paʊɝfəl wəd meɪk ə bɛɾɝ fɹɛn ðən foʊ, aɪ seɪ."

"I'd make an alliance, my Lord," Ramshalan said without pausing for another second. "Anyone that powerful would make a better friend than foe, I say."

ɪɾiət, mɪn θɔt. ɪf jəɹ ɛnəmi ɪz ðət kɹæfti ən ɹuθləs, ən əlaɪəns wɪl oʊnli ɛnd wɪð ən əsæsənz dæɡɝ ɪn jəɹ bæk.

Idiot, Min thought. If your enemy is that crafty and ruthless, an alliance will only end with an assassin's dagger in your back.

"ənʌðɝ ɛksələn sədʒɛstʃən," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. "bʌɾ aɪm stɪl ɪntʃɹiɡd baɪ ðə fɝs kɑmɛn jə meɪd. jə sɛɾ aɪ niɾ ælaɪz u ɑɹ smɑɹɾɝ ðən aɪ æm, ən ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹu. ɪts taɪm fəɹ jə tə bi ɔf, ðɛn."

"Another excellent suggestion," Rand said softly. "But I am still intrigued by the first comment you made. You said I need allies who are smarter than I am, and that is true. It is time for you to be off, then."

"maɪ lɔɹd?" ɹæmʃələn sɛd.

"My Lord?" Ramshalan said.

"ju ɑɹ tə bi maɪ ɛməsɛɹi," ɹænd sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ɪz hænd. ə ɡeɪtweɪ sʌɾənli splɪt ði ɛɹ ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, ʃɪɹɪŋ θɹu ðə faɪn ɹʌɡ ət ðə flɔɹ. "tu mɛni ʌv ðə dəmɑni blʌdbɔɹn ɑɹ haɪɾɪŋ, skæɾɝd θɹu ðə kʌntʃɹi. aɪ wəɾ əv əm əz maɪ ælaɪz, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi ə dʒɹeɪn ɑn maɪ taɪm tə sik itʃ wʌn ɪn pɝsən. fɔɹtʃənətli, aɪ hæv jə tə ɡoʊ ɑn maɪ bɪhæf."

"You are to be my emissary," Rand said, waving his hand. A gateway suddenly split the air on the far side of the room, shearing through the fine rug at the floor. "Too many of the Domani bloodborn are hiding, scattered through the country. I would have them as my allies, but it would be a drain on my time to seek each one in person. Fortunately, I have you to go on my behalf."

ɹæmʃələn lʊkt ɪksaɪɾəd əbaʊt ðə pɹɑspɛkt. θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, mɪn kəd si taʊɝɪŋ paɪnz, ən ði ɛɹ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd wɑz koʊld ən kɹɪsp. mɪn tɝn ən ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv - dʒɹɛst ɪn blu ən waɪɾ əɡɛn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑtʃt ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ wɪð kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ aɪz, ən mɪn kəd ɹiɾ əɹ oʊn ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn nɪneɪivz ɪkspɹɛʃən. wʌt wɑz ɹændz ɡeɪm?

Ramshalan looked excited about the prospect. Through the gateway, Min could see towering pines, and the air on the other side was cold and crisp. Min turned and glanced at Nynaeve - dressed in blue and white again. The Aes Sedai watched the exchange with calculating eyes, and Min could read her own emotions in Nynaeve's expression. What was Rand's game?

"bɪɑn ðət ɡeɪtweɪ," ɹænd sɛd, "ju wɪl faɪn ə hɪl liɾɪŋ daʊn tə ən eɪntʃən pæləs wɪtʃ ɪz ɪnhæbəɾəd baɪ ə maɪnɝ dəmɑni mɝtʃən fæmli. ɪts ðə fɝst ə mɛni pleɪsəz aɪ ʃæl sɛn ju. ɡoʊ ɪn maɪ neɪm ən sik ðoʊz u ɹul ðə kip. si ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ wɪlɪŋ tə səpɔɹt mi, əɹ ɪf ðeɪ ivən noʊ əbaʊt mi. ɔfɝ əm ɹɪwɔɹdz fəɹ əlidʒəns; sɪns juv pɹuvən jɝsɛlf klɛvɝ, əl lɛt jə dətɝmən ðə tɝmz. aɪ hævən ðə maɪn fəɹ ðoʊz sɔɹts ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz maɪsɛlf."

"Beyond that gateway," Rand said, "you will find a hill leading down to an ancient palace which is inhabited by a minor Domani merchant family. It is the first of many places I shall send you. Go in my name and seek those who rule the keep. See if they are willing to support me, or if they even know about me. Offer them rewards for allegiance; since you have proven yourself clever, I will let you determine the terms. I haven't the mind for those sorts of negotiations myself."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd!" ðə mæn sɛd, swɛlɪŋ fɝðɝ, ðoʊ hi dɪɾ aɪ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪð kənsɝn, dɪstʃɹʌsfəl - laɪk moʊs pipəl - ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən wildɪd baɪ ə mæn. ɪf ɪt wɝ ɑpɝtun, ðɪs mæn wəd swɪtʃ lɔɪəltiz əz kwɪkli əz i hæd wən leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝ hæd fɔlən. wʌt wɑz ɹænd θɪŋkɪŋ, sɛndɪŋ ə poʊpənʒ laɪk ðɪs tə mit wɪð ɡɹeɪndəl?

"Yes, my Lord!" the man said, swelling further, though he did eye the gateway with concern, distrustful - like most people - of the One Power, particularly when wielded by a man. If it were opportune, this man would switch loyalties as quickly as he had when Lady Chadmar had fallen. What was Rand thinking, sending a popinjay like this to meet with Graendal?

"ɡoʊ," ɹænd sɛd.

"Go," Rand said.

ɹæmʃələn tʊk ə fju hɛzɪɾənt stɛps təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. "ɝ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, kəɾ aɪ pɝhæps əv sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ən ɛskɔɹt?"

Ramshalan took a few hesitant steps toward the gateway. "Er, my Lord Dragon, could I perhaps have something in the way of an escort?"

"noʊ nid tə fɹaɪɾən əɹ əlɑɹm ðə pipəl ðɛɹ," ɹænd sɛd wɪθaʊt tɝnɪŋ fɹəm ðə mæp. koʊld ɛɹ kəntɪnjud tə bloʊ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. "ɡoʊ kwɪkli ən ɹɪtɝn, ɹæmʃələn. əl liv ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən əntɪl jə ɑɹ bæk. maɪ peɪʃəns ɪz nɑt lɪmətləs, ən ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni aɪ kəd tɝn tə fəɹ ðɪs mɪʃən."

"No need to frighten or alarm the people there," Rand said without turning from the map. Cold air continued to blow through the gateway. "Go quickly and return, Ramshalan. I will leave the gateway open until you are back. My patience is not limitless, and there are many I could turn to for this mission."

"aɪ. . . ." ðə mæn sim tə kælkjəleɪt ðə ɹɪsks. "ʌv kɔɹs, lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən wɔk θɹu ðə pɔɹɾəl, hɪz stɛps ənkʌmftəɹbəl, laɪk ðoʊz ʌv ə haʊs kæt vɛntʃɝɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ə pʌɾəl ʌv wɔɾɝ. mɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf filɪŋ sɑɹi fəɹ ðə mæn.

"I. . . ." The man seemed to calculate the risks. "Of course, Lord Dragon." He took a deep breath and walked through the portal, his steps uncomfortable, like those of a house cat venturing out into a puddle of water. Min found herself feeling sorry for the man.

fɔlən niɾəlz kɹækəld əz ɹæmʃələn muvd ɔf ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst. ə bɹiz hɪs θɹu ðə tʃɹiz; ɪt wɑz ən ɑd saʊn tə hɪɹ waɪl stændɪŋ ɪn ðə kʌmfɝɾ ə ðə mænʃən. ɹænd lɛf ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪz mæp.

Fallen needles crackled as Ramshalan moved off into the forest. A breeze hissed through the trees; it was an odd sound to hear while standing in the comfort of the mansion. Rand left the gateway open, still staring at his map.

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ɹænd," nɪneɪiv dɪmændəɾ æftɝ ə fju mɪnəts, hɝ ɑɹmz foʊldəd. "wʌt ɡeɪm ɪz ðɪs?"

"All right, Rand," Nynaeve demanded after a few minutes, her arms folded. "What game is this?"

"haʊ wəd jə bit hɝ, nɪneɪiv?" ɹænd æskt. "ʃi woʊn bi ɡoʊɾɪd ɪndə faɪɾɪŋ mi, laɪk ɹɑvɪn əɹ sɑmaɪl wɝ. ʃi woʊn bi izəli tʃɹæpt iðɝ. ɡɹeɪndəl ʌndɝstænz pipəl bɛɾɝ ðən ɛniwʌn. twɪstəd ʃi meɪ bi, bʌt ʃiz kɹæfti, ən ʃəd nɑt bi ʌndɝɛstəmeɪɾɪd. ɔɹs mɑɹdʒən meɪd ðət mɪsteɪk, aɪ ɹikɔl, ən jə noʊ hɪz feɪt."

"How would you beat her, Nynaeve?" Rand asked. "She won't be goaded into fighting me, like Rahvin or Sammael were. She won't be easily trapped either. Graendal understands people better than anyone. Twisted she may be, but she is crafty, and should not be underestimated. Torhs Margin made that mistake, I recall, and you know his fate."

mɪn fɹaʊnd. "hu?" ʃi æskt, lʊkɪŋ ət nɪneɪiv. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃɹʌɡd.

Min frowned. "Who?" she asked, looking at Nynaeve. The Aes Sedai shrugged.

ɹænd ɡlænst ət ðɛm. "aɪ bɪliv ɪn hɪstɝi hi wɑz noʊn əz tɑɹz ðə bɹoʊkən."

Rand glanced at them. "I believe in history he was known as Tohrs the Broken."

əɡɛn, mɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. nɪneɪiv dʒɔɪn hɝ. niðɝ wɑz dipli vɝst ɪn hɪstɝi, tʃɹu, bʌt ɹænd æktəɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ ʃəd noʊ ðɪs neɪm. ɹændz feɪs hɑɹɾənd, ən i blʌʃt dʒʌs feɪnli, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm. "ðə kwɛstʃən ɹɪmeɪnz," hi sɛd, vɔɪs sɑf bʌt tɛns. "haʊ wəd jə faɪt hɝ, nɪneɪiv?"

Again, Min shook her head. Nynaeve joined her. Neither was deeply versed in history, true, but Rand acted as if they should know this name. Rand's face hardened, and he blushed just faintly, turning away from them. "The question remains," he said, voice soft but tense. "How would you fight her, Nynaeve?"

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ tə pleɪ jəɹ ɡeɪmz, ɹænd ælθɹ," nɪneɪiv ɹɪplaɪd wɪð ə hʌf. "juv ɑbviəsli ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsaɪɾɪd wʌt jə ɪntɛn tə du. waɪ æsk mi?"

"I don't care to play your games, Rand al'Thor," Nynaeve replied with a huff. "You've obviously already decided what you intend to do. Why ask me?"

"bɪkɔz wʌɾ aɪm əbaʊt tə də ʃəd fɹaɪɾən mi," hi sɛd. "ɪt dʌznt."

"Because what I am about to do should frighten me," he said. "It doesn't."

mɪn ʃɪvɝd. ɹænd nɑɾəd tə ðə meɪɾənz stændɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. muvɪŋ laɪtli, ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə ɹum, lɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən spɹɛd θɹu ðə paɪn fɔɹəst, kwɪkli vænɪʃɪŋ fɹəm saɪt. ɔl twɛnti təɡɛðɝ meɪd lɛs nɔɪz ðən ɹæmʃələn hæd.

Min shivered. Rand nodded to the Maidens standing in the doorway. Moving lightly, they crossed the room, leaped through the gateway, and spread through the pine forest, quickly vanishing from sight. All twenty together made less noise than Ramshalan had.

mɪn weɪɾəd. ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ə dɪstən sʌn wɑz hɪɾən fɹəm saɪt, ɡɪvɪŋ ə leɪt- æftɝnun laɪt tə ðə ʃæɾoʊd fɔɹəs flɔɹ. æftɝ ə fju moʊməns, waɪt-hɛɹd nɛɝɪliə stɛpt ɪndə vju ən nɑɾəd tə ɹænd. ɔl klɪɹ.

Min waited. On the other side of the gateway, a distant sun was hidden from sight, giving a late- afternoon light to the shadowed forest floor. After a few moments, white-haired Nerilea stepped into view and nodded to Rand. All clear.

"kʌm," ɹænd sɛd, ən wɔk tə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. mɪn fɑloʊd, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv - bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪndə ə tʃɹɑt - biɾ əɹ tə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ.

"Come," Rand said, and walked to the gateway. Min followed, though Nynaeve - breaking into a trot - beat her to the gateway.

ðeɪ stɛpt aʊɾ ɑntu ə kɑɹpəɾ ə bɹaʊn paɪn niɾəlz, dɝɾid fɹəm ə lɔŋ slʌmbɝ bɪniθ ðə vænɪʃt wɪntɝ snoʊz. bɹæntʃəz nʌdʒd wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə bɹiz, ən ðə maʊntən ɛɹ wɑz mɔɹ tʃɪli ðən ðə bɹiz hæɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd. mɪn wɪʃt fəɹ ə kloʊk, bʌt ðəɹ wɑzn taɪm tə ɡoʊ fɛtʃ wʌn.

They stepped out onto a carpet of brown pine needles, dirtied from a long slumber beneath the vanished winter snows. Branches nudged one another in the breeze, and the mountain air was more chilly than the breeze had indicated. Min wished for a cloak, but there wasn't time to go fetch one.

ɹænd stʃɹoʊd dɝɛkli θɹu ðə fɔɹəst, nɪneɪiv tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ʌp tə hɪm ən spikɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs.

Rand strode directly through the forest, Nynaeve trotting up to him and speaking in a low voice.

nɪneɪiv wʊdnt ɡɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl aʊɾ ə ɹænd, nɑt wən i wɑz ɪn ðɪs kaɪndə mud. ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst əv tə si wʌɾ i ɹɪvild. mɪn kɑt saɪɾ ə səm il ɪn ðə wʊdz, bʌɾ oʊnli bɹif ɡlɪmpsɪz wən ðeɪ ɑbviəsli wɝn teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ tə haɪd. ðeɪ sɝɾənli hæd teɪkən wɛl tə laɪf ɪn ðə wɛtlænz. haʊ dɪɾ ə pipəl ɹeɪzd ɪn ðə weɪs noʊ soʊ ɪnstɪŋktɪvli haʊ tə haɪɾ ɪn ə fɔɹəst?

Nynaeve wouldn't get anything useful out of Rand, not when he was in this kind of mood. They would just have to see what he revealed. Min caught sight of some Aiel in the woods, but only brief glimpses when they obviously weren't taking care to hide. They certainly had taken well to life in the wetlands. How did a people raised in the Waste know so instinctively how to hide in a forest?

ʌp əhɛd, ðə tʃɹiz bɹoʊk. mɪn heɪsən tə dʒɔɪn ɹænd ən nɪneɪiv, hu hæd stɑpt ət ðə tɑp ʌv ə dʒɛnli sloʊpɪŋ ɹɪdʒ. hɪɹ, ðeɪ kəd si oʊvɝ ðə fɔɹəst, ən ðə tʃɹiz kəntɪnjud daʊn bɪloʊ laɪk ə si ʌv ɡɹin ən bɹaʊn. ðə paɪnz pɑɹɾəd ət ðə ʃɔɹz ʌv ə smɔl maʊntən leɪk, kɑɾ ɪn ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ dɪpɹɛʃən ə ðə lænd.

Up ahead, the trees broke. Min hastened to join Rand and Nynaeve, who had stopped at the top of a gently sloping ridge. Here, they could see over the forest, and the trees continued down below like a sea of green and brown. The pines parted at the shores of a small mountain lake, caught in a triangular depression of the land.

ətɑp ə ɹɪdʒ ʌv ɪts oʊn, haɪ əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝ, wɑz ən ɪmpɹɛsɪv waɪt stoʊn stʃɹʌktʃɝ.

Atop a ridge of its own, high above the water, was an impressive white stone structure.

ɹɛktæŋɡjəlɝ ən tɔl, ɪt wɑz bɪlt ɪn ðə fɔɹm ə sɛvɹəl taʊɝz stækt ətɑp wʌn ənʌðɝ, itʃ wʌn slaɪtli θɪnɝ ðən ðə wʌn bɪniθ. ðət ɡeɪv ðə pæləs ən ɛləɡənt ʃeɪp - fɔɹɾəfaɪd, jɛt pəleɪʃəl.

Rectangular and tall, it was built in the form of several towers stacked atop one another, each one slightly thinner than the one beneath. That gave the palace an elegant shape - fortified, yet palatial.

"ɪts bjuɾəfəl," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθləsli.

"It's beautiful," she said breathlessly.

"ɪt wɑz bɪl dʊɹɪŋ ə dɪfɹən taɪm," ɹænd sɛd. "ə taɪm wən pipəl stɪl θɔt ðət ðə mædʒəsti ʌv ə stʃɹʌktʃɝ lɛn ɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ."

"It was built during a different time," Rand said. "A time when people still thought that the majesty of a structure lent it strength."

ðə pæləs wɑz dɪstənt, bʌt nɑt soʊ dɪstən ðət mɪn kʊdn meɪk aʊt ðə fɪɡjɝz ə mɛn wɔkɪŋ ðə bæɾəlmənts ɑn ɡɑɹd, hælbɝdz ət ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, bɹɛstpleɪts ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə leɪt sʌnlaɪt. ə leɪt pɑɹɾi ʌv hʌntɝz ɹoʊɾ ɪn θɹu ðə ɡeɪts, ə faɪn bʌk dɪɹ læʃt tə ðə pækhɔɹs, ən ə ɡɹup ʌv wɝkɝz tʃɑpt əɾ ə fɔlən tʃɹi nɪɹbaɪ, pɝhæps fəɹ faɪɝwʊd. ə pɛɹ ə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən ɪn waɪt kæɹid poʊlz, bʌkəɾ əɾ itʃ ɛnd, ʌp fɹəm ðə leɪk, ən laɪts wɝ wɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ɪn wɪndoʊz ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə stʃɹʌktʃɝ. ɪt wɑz ə lɪvɪŋ, wɝkɪŋ ɪsteɪt bʌndəld ʌp ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl mæsɪv bɪldɪŋ.

The palace was distant, but not so distant that Min couldn't make out the figures of men walking the battlements on guard, halberds at their shoulders, breastplates reflecting the late sunlight. A late party of hunters rode in through the gates, a fine buck deer lashed to the packhorse, and a group of workers chopped at a fallen tree nearby, perhaps for firewood. A pair of serving women in white carried poles, bucket at each end, up from the lake, and lights were winking on in windows the length of the structure. It was a living, working estate bundled up in a single massive building.

"du jə θɪŋk ɹæmʃələn faʊn ɪz weɪ?" nɪneɪiv sɛd, ɑɹmz foʊldəd, ɑbviəsli tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lʊk ɪmpɹɛst.

"Do you think Ramshalan found his way?" Nynaeve said, arms folded, obviously trying not to look impressed.

"ivən ə ful laɪk ɪm kəd nɑt mɪs ðæt," ɹænd sɛd, aɪz nɛɹoʊɪŋ. hi stɪl kæɹid ðə stætʃuɛɾ ɪn ɪz pɑkət. mɪn wɪʃt i hæd lɛf ðə θɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. ɪt meɪɾ əɹ ənkʌmftəɹbəl, ðə weɪ hi fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪt. kɝɛst ɪt.

"Even a fool like him could not miss that," Rand said, eyes narrowing. He still carried the statuette in his pocket. Min wished he had left the thing behind. It made her uncomfortable, the way he fingered it. Caressed it.

"soʊ jə sɛn ɹæmʃələn tə daɪ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "wʌt wɪl ðəɾ əkɑmplɪʃ?"

"So you sent Ramshalan to die," Nynaeve said. "What will that accomplish?"

"ʃi woʊn kɪl hɪm," ɹænd sɛd.

"She won't kill him," Rand said.

"haʊ kən jə bi ʃʊɹ ə ðæt?"

"How can you be sure of that?"

"ɪɾ ɪzən əɹ weɪ," ɹænd sɛd. "nɑt wən ʃi kən juz ɪm əɡɛns mi."

"It isn't her way," Rand said. "Not when she can use him against me."

"ju doʊn ɪkspɛkt əɹ tə bɪliv ðət stɔɹi jə toʊl hɪm," mɪn sɛd. "əbaʊt sɛndɪŋ ɪm aʊt tə tɛs ði əlidʒəns ə ðə dəmɑni lɔɹdz?"

"You don't expect her to believe that story you told him," Min said. "About sending him out to test the allegiance of the Domani lords?"

ɹænd sloʊli ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ. aɪ hoʊp fəɹ əɹ tə bɪliv sʌmθɪŋ ə ðət teɪl, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɪt. aɪ mɛnt wʌɾ aɪ sɛɾ əbaʊt hɝ, mɪn - ʃiz mɔɹ kɹæfti ðən aɪ æm. ən aɪ fɪɹ ðət ʃi noʊz mi fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ noʊ hɝ. ʃɪl kəmpɛl ɹæmʃələn ən pʊl fɹəm ɪm ðəɾ ɪntaɪɝ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wi hæd. fɹəm ðɛɹ, ʃɪl faɪn ə weɪ tə juz ðət kɑnvɝseɪʃən əɡɛns mi."

Rand slowly shook his head. "No. I hope for her to believe something of that tale, but I do not expect it. I meant what I said about her, Min - she's more crafty than I am. And I fear that she knows me far better than I know her. She will compel Ramshalan and pull from him that entire conversation we had. From there, she will find a way to use that conversation against me."

"haʊ?" mɪn æskt.

"How?" Min asked.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ dɪd. ʃɪl θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ klɛvɝ, ðən ɪnfɛkt ɹæmʃələn wɪð ə vɛɹi sʌɾəl kəmpʌlʃən ðəɾ aɪ woʊn bi eɪbəl tə æntɪsəpeɪt. əl bi lɛft wɪð ðə tʃɔɪs tə kip ɪm nɪɹbaɪ ən si wʌɾ i dʌz, əɹ tə sɛn ɪm əweɪ. bʌɾ ə kɔɹs, ʃɪl θɪŋk ə ðəɾ əz wɛl, ən wʌtɛvɝ aɪ də wɪl sɛɾ ɪn moʊʃən əɹ ʌðɝ plænz."

"I don't know. I wish I did. She'll think of something clever, then infect Ramshalan with a very subtle Compulsion that I won't be able to anticipate. I'll be left with the choice to keep him nearby and see what he does, or to send him away. But of course, she will think of that as well, and whatever I do will set in motion her other plans."

"ju meɪk ɪt saʊn əz ɪf jə kænt wɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ʃi dɪdn sim tə noʊɾəs ðə tʃɪl əɾ ɔl. ɪn fækt, niðɝ dɪd ɹænd. wʌtɛvɝ ðət "tʃɹɪk" əbaʊɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ koʊld ən hit wɑz, mɪn hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə fɪɡjɝ ɪɾ aʊt. ðeɪ kleɪmd ɪt hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ, bʌɾ ɪf ðət wɝ soʊ, waɪ wɝ ɹænd ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ði oʊnli wʌnz u kəd mænədʒ ɪt? ði il dɪdn sim tə bi bɑðɝd baɪ ðə koʊld iðɝ, bʌt ðeɪ dɪdn kaʊnt. ðeɪ nɛvɝ sim bɑðɝd baɪ ɹɛɡjəlɝ hjumən kənsɝnz, ðoʊ ðeɪ kəd bi vɛɹi tʌtʃi əbaʊt ðə moʊst ɹændəm ən ɪnsɪɡnjɪfɪkən θɪŋz.

"You make it sound as if you can't win," Nynaeve said, frowning. She didn't seem to notice the chill at all. In fact, neither did Rand. Whatever that "trick" about ignoring cold and heat was, Min had never been able to figure it out. They claimed it had nothing to do with the power, but if that were so, why were Rand and the Aes Sedai the only ones who could manage it? The Aiel didn't seem to be bothered by the cold either, but they didn't count. They never seemed bothered by regular human concerns, though they could be very touchy about the most random and insignificant things.

"wi kænt wɪn, jə seɪ?" ɹænd æskt. "ɪz ðət wʌt wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə du? wɪn?"

"We can't win, you say?" Rand asked. "Is that what we're trying to do? Win?"

nɪneɪiv ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "du jə nɑɾ ænsɝ kwɛstʃənz ɛnimɔɹ?"

Nynaeve raised an eyebrow. "Do you not answer questions anymore?"

ɹænd tɝnd, lʊkɪŋ ət nɪneɪiv. stændɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm, mɪn kʊdn si wʌt wɑz ɪn ɪz feɪs, bʌt ʃi kəd si nɪneɪiv ɡɹoʊ peɪl. ɪt wɑz əɹ oʊn fɔlt. kʊdnt ʃi sɛns haʊ ɑn ɛdʒ ɹænd wɑz? pɝhæps mɪnz tʃɪl dɪdn dʒʌs kʌm fɹəm ðə koʊld. ʃi muvd ʌp kloʊs tə hɪm, bʌɾ i dɪdn pʊɾ ɪz ɑɹm ɝaʊn əɹ əz i maɪt wʌns hæv. wən i faɪnəli tɝn əweɪ fɹəm nɪneɪiv, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ slʌmp slaɪtli, əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn dæŋɡəlɪŋ, hɛld ʌp baɪ hɪz ɡeɪz.

Rand turned, looking at Nynaeve. Standing on the other side of him, Min couldn't see what was in his face, but she could see Nynaeve grow pale. It was her own fault. Couldn't she sense how on edge Rand was? Perhaps Min's chill didn't just come from the cold. She moved up close to him, but he didn't put his arm around her as he might once have. When he finally turned away from Nynaeve, the Aes Sedai slumped slightly, as if she had been dangling, held up by his gaze.

ɹænd dɪd nɑt spik fəɹ səm taɪm, ən soʊ ðeɪ weɪɾəd kwaɪətli ɑn ðə maʊntən ɹɪdʒ əz ðə dɪstən sʌn meɪɾ ɪts weɪ təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən. ʃædoʊz lɛŋθənd, fɪŋɡɝz stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə sʌn.

Rand did not speak for some time, and so they waited quietly on the mountain ridge as the distant sun made its way toward the horizon. Shadows lengthened, fingers stretching away from the sun.

daʊn bɪloʊ, baɪ ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs wɔlz, ə ɡɹup ʌv ɡɹumz bɪɡæn wɔkɪŋ səm hɔɹsəz tə ɡɪv əm ɛksɝsaɪz. mɔɹ laɪts hæd bɪn lɪɾ ɪn ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs wɪndoʊz. haʊ mɛni pipəl dɪd ɡɹeɪndəl əv ɪn ðɛɹ? skɔɹz, ɪf nɑt hʌnʒɹədz.

Down below, by the fortress walls, a group of grooms began walking some horses to give them exercise. More lights had been lit in the fortress windows. How many people did Graendal have in there? Scores, if not hundreds.

ə kɹæʃɪŋ saʊn ɪn ðə bɹʌʃ sʌɾənli dʒɹu mɪnz ətɛnʃən; ɪt wɑz əkʌmpənid baɪ kɝsɪz. ʃi dʒʌmpt əz ðə nɔɪz kʌɾ ɔf kwaɪɾ əbɹʌpli.

A crashing sound in the brush suddenly drew Min's attention; it was accompanied by curses. She jumped as the noise cut off quite abruptly.

ə smɔl ɡɹup ʌv il əpɹoʊtʃt ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ, liɾɪŋ ə dɪʃɛvəld ɹæmʃələn, hɪz faɪn kloʊðɪŋ stʌk wɪð niɾəlz ən skɹætʃt fɹəm bɹæntʃəz. hi dʌstɪd hɪmsɛlf ɔf, ðən tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd ɹænd.

A small group of Aiel approached a few moments later, leading a disheveled Ramshalan, his fine clothing stuck with needles and scratched from branches. He dusted himself off, then took a step toward Rand.

ðə meɪɾənz hɛld ɪm bæk. hi ɡlænst ət ðɛm, kɑkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən?"

The Maidens held him back. He glanced at them, cocking his head. "My Lord Dragon?"

"ɪz i ɪnfɛktəd?" ɹænd æskt ə nɪneɪiv.

"Is he infected?" Rand asked of Nynaeve.

"baɪ wʌt?" ʃi æskt.

"By what?" she asked.

"ɡɹeɪndəlz tʌtʃ."

"Graendal's touch."

nɪneɪiv wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ɹæmʃələn ən lʊkt əɾ ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ʃi hɪst ən sɛd, "jɛs.

Nynaeve walked over to Ramshalan and looked at him for a moment. She hissed and said, "Yes.

ɹænd, hiz ʌndɝ ə hɛvi kəmpʌlʃən. ðəɹ ɑɹ ə lɑɾ ʌv wivz hɪɹ. nɑɾ əz bæɾ əz ðə tʃænlɝz əpɹɛntəs, əɹ meɪbi dʒʌs mɔɹ sʌɾəl."

Rand, he's under a heavy Compulsion. There are a lot of weaves here. Not as bad as the chandler's apprentice, or maybe just more subtle."

"aɪ seɪ," ɹæmʃələn sɛd, "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, wʌɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn? ðə leɪɾi ʌv ðə kæsəl daʊn ðəɹ wɑz kwaɪt fɹɛnli - ʃiz ən ælaɪ, maɪ lɔɹd. juv nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ fɹəm hɝ! vɛɹi ɹəfaɪnd, aɪ mʌst seɪ."

"I say," Ramshalan said, "my Lord Dragon, what is going on? The lady of the castle down there was quite friendly - she is an ally, my Lord. You have nothing to fear from her! Very refined, I must say."

"ɪz ðət soʊ?" ɹænd æskt kwaɪətli. ɪt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹk, sʌn sɛɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə dɪstən maʊntənz.

"Is that so?" Rand asked quietly. It was growing dark, sun setting behind the distant mountains.

bɪsaɪdz ðə dɪm ivnɪŋ laɪt, ði oʊnli ɪluməneɪʃən keɪm fɹəm ðə stɪl-oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ɪt ʃoʊn wɪð læmplaɪt, ən ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ pɔɹɾəl bæk tə wɔɹmθ, əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs pleɪs ə ʃædoʊ ən koʊlnəs.

Besides the dim evening light, the only illumination came from the still-open gateway behind them. It shone with lamplight, an inviting portal back to warmth, away from this place of shadow and coldness.

ɹændz vɔɪs saʊndəd soʊ hɑɹd. wɝs ðən mɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ.

Rand's voice sounded so hard. Worse than Min had ever heard it before.

"ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, tʌtʃɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm. "lɛts ɡoʊ bæk."

"Rand," she said, touching his arm. "Let's go back."

"aɪ hæv sʌmθɪŋ aɪ mʌs du," hi sɛd, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ.

"I have something I must do," he said, not looking at her.

"θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt səm mɔɹ," mɪn sɛd. "æt lis teɪk səm ædvaɪs. wi kən æsk kædzueɪn, əɹ - "

"Think about it some more," Min said. "At least take some advice. We can ask Cadsuane, or - "

"kædzueɪn hɛl mi ɪn ə bɑks, mɪn," hi sɛd vɛɹi sɔfli. hɪz feɪs wɑz klæspt ɪn ʃædoʊ, bʌɾ əz i tɝn təwɔɹd hɝ, hɪz aɪz ɹəflɛktəd ðə laɪt fɹəm ði oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ. ɔɹənʒ ən ɹɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛdʒ ʌv æŋɡɝ tə hɪz toʊn. aɪ ʃʊdn əv mɛnʃən kædzueɪn, ʃi ɹilaɪzd. ðə wʊmənz neɪm wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju θɪŋz ðət kəd stɪl ɡɛɾ ɪmoʊʃən aʊɾ ə hɪm.

"Cadsuane held me in a box, Min," he said very softly. His face was clasped in shadow, but as he turned toward her, his eyes reflected the light from the open gateway. Orange and red. There was an edge of anger to his tone. I shouldn't have mentioned Cadsuane, she realized. The woman's name was one of the few things that could still get emotion out of him.

"ə bɑks, mɪn," ɹænd wɪspɝd. "ðoʊ kædzueɪnz bɑks hæd wɔlz ðət wɝ ɪnvɪzəbəl, ɪt wɑz əz baɪndɪŋ əz ɛni ðəɾ ɛvɝ hɛl mi. hɝ tʌŋ wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ peɪnfəl ə ɹɑd ðən ɛni ðət wɑz teɪkən tə maɪ skɪn. aɪ si ðət naʊ."

"A box, Min," Rand whispered. "Though Cadsuane's box had walls that were invisible, it was as binding as any that ever held me. Her tongue was far more painful a rod than any that was taken to my skin. I see that now."

ɹænd pʊld əweɪ fɹəm mɪnz tʌtʃ.

Rand pulled away from Min's touch.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə pɝpəs ʌv ɔl ðɪs?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. "ju sɛn ðɪs mæn tə sʌfɝ ə kəmpʌlʃən, noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt wəd də tə hɪm? aɪ woʊnt wɑtʃ ənʌðɝ mæn skwɝm ən daɪ kəz ə ðɪs!

"What is the purpose of all this?" Nynaeve demanded. "You sent this man to suffer a Compulsion, knowing what it would do to him? I won't watch another man squirm and die because of this!

wʌtɛvɝ ʃiz kəmpɛld ɪm tə du, aɪ woʊn ɹimuv ɪt! ɪɾəl bi jəɹ oʊn fɔlt ɪf ɪt bɹɪŋz jəɹ dɛθ."

Whatever she has compelled him to do, I won't remove it! It will be your own fault if it brings your death."

"maɪ lɔɹd?" ɹæmʃələn æskt. ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ tɛɹɝ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs pʊt mɪn ɑn ɛdʒ.

"My Lord?" Ramshalan asked. The growing terror in his voice put Min on edge.

ðə sʌn sɛt; ɹænd wɑz naʊ dʒʌst ə sɪləwɛt. ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs wɑz oʊnli ə blæk pɹoʊfaɪl wɪð læntɝnz laɪɾɪŋ ðə hoʊlz ɪn ɪts wɔlz. ɹænd stɛpt ʌp tə ðə lɪp ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, ɹimuvɪŋ ði æksɛs ki fɹəm ɪz pɑkət. ɪt stɑɹɾəd tə ɡloʊ dʒʌs feɪnli, ə ɹɛd laɪt kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ɪts vɛɹi hɑɹt. nɪneɪiv ɪnheɪld ʃɑɹpli.

The sun set; Rand was now just a silhouette. The fortress was only a black profile with lanterns lighting the holes in its walls. Rand stepped up to the lip of the ridge, removing the access key from his pocket. It started to glow just faintly, a red light coming from its very heart. Nynaeve inhaled sharply.

"niðɝ ə jə wɝ ðəɹ wən kælændɝ feɪl mi," hi sɛɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt. "ɪt hæpən twaɪs.

"Neither of you were there when Callandor failed me," he said into the night. "It happened twice.

wʌns aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə juz ɪt tə ɹeɪz ðə dɛd, bʌɾ aɪ ɡɑɾ oʊnli ə pʌpəɾɪd bɑɾi. wʌns aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə juz ɪt tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə sintʃæn, bʌɾ aɪ kɑzd əz mʌtʃ dɛθ əmʌŋ maɪ oʊn ɑɹmiz əz aɪ kɑzd əmʌŋ ðɛɹz.

Once I tried to use it to raise the dead, but I got only a puppeted body. Once I tried to use it to destroy the Seanchan, but I caused as much death among my own armies as I caused among theirs.

"kædzueɪn toʊl mi ðət ðə sɛkən feɪljɝ keɪm fɹəm ə flɔ ɪn kælændɝ ɪtsɛlf. ɪt kænɑt bi kəntʃɹoʊl baɪ ə loʊn mæn, jə si. ɪɾ oʊnli wɝks ɪf hiz ɪn ə bɑks. kælændɝ ɪz ə kɛɹfəli ɛntaɪsɪŋ liʃ, ɪntɛndəd tə meɪk mi sɝɛndɝ wɪlɪŋli."

"Cadsuane told me that the second failure came from a flaw in Callandor itself. It cannot be controlled by a lone man, you see. It only works if he's in a box. Callandor is a carefully enticing leash, intended to make me surrender willingly."

ði æksɛs kiz ɡloʊb bɝst əlaɪt wɪð ə mɔɹ bɹɪljən kʌlɝ, simɪŋ kɹɪstəlaɪn. ðə laɪt wɪðɪn wɑz skɑɹlət, ðə kɔɹ bɹɪljən ən bɹaɪt. əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd dʒɹɑpt ə ɡloʊɪŋ ɹɑk ɪndə ə pul ə blʌd.

The access key's globe burst alight with a more brilliant color, seeming crystalline. The light within was scarlet, the core brilliant and bright. As if someone had dropped a glowing rock into a pool of blood.

"aɪ si ə dɪfɹən ænsɝ tə maɪ pɹɑbləmz," ɹænd sɛd, vɔɪs stɪl ɔlmoʊst ə wɪspɝ. "boʊθ taɪmz kælændɝ feɪl mi, aɪ wɑz biɪŋ ɹɛkləs wɪð maɪ ɪmoʊʃən. aɪ əlaʊd tɛmpɝ tə dʒɹaɪv mi. aɪ kæn kɪl ɪn æŋɡɝ, mɪn. aɪ hæv tə kip ðəɾ æŋɡɝ ɪnsaɪd; aɪ mʌs tʃænəl ɪɾ əz aɪ tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ. itʃ dɛθ mʌs bi dɪlɪbɝɪt. ɪntɛnʃənəl."

"I see a different answer to my problems," Rand said, voice still almost a whisper. "Both times Callandor failed me, I was being reckless with my emotion. I allowed temper to drive me. I can't kill in anger, Min. I have to keep that anger inside; I must channel it as I channel the One Power. Each death must be deliberate. Intentional."

mɪn kʊdn spik. kʊdn fɹeɪz əɹ fɪɹz, kʊdn faɪn ðə wɝdz tə meɪk ɪm stɑp. hɪz aɪz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, sʌmhaʊ, dɪspaɪt ðə lɪkwəd laɪɾ i hɛl bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ðət laɪt hɝld ʃædoʊz əweɪ fɹəm ɪz fɪɡjɝ, əz ɪf i wɑz ðə pɔɪn ʌv ə saɪlən ɪksploʊʒən. mɪn tɝn tə nɪneɪiv; ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑtʃt wɪð waɪɾ aɪz, maʊθ slaɪtli oʊpən. ʃi kʊdn faɪnd wɝdz iðɝ.

Min couldn't speak. Couldn't phrase her fears, couldn't find the words to make him stop. His eyes remained in the darkness, somehow, despite the liquid light he held before him. That light hurled shadows away from his figure, as if he was the point of a silent explosion. Min turned to Nynaeve; the Aes Sedai watched with wide eyes, mouth slightly open. She couldn't find words either.

mɪn tɝn bæk tə ɹænd. wən hid bɪn kloʊs tə kɪlɪŋ əɹ wɪð ɪz oʊn hænd, ʃi hædn fɪɹd hɪm. bʌt ðɛn, ʃid noʊn ðəɾ ɪt wɑzn ɹænd hɝɾɪŋ hɝ, bʌt sɛmɝhɪdʒ.

Min turned back to Rand. When he'd been close to killing her with his own hand, she hadn't feared him. But then, she'd known that it wasn't Rand hurting her, but Semirhage.

bʌt ðɪs ɹænd - hæn əfleɪm, aɪz soʊ ɪntɛn jɛt soʊ dɪspæʃənət - tɛɹəfaɪd hɝ.

But this Rand - hand aflame, eyes so intent yet so dispassionate - terrified her.

"aɪv dʌn ɪt bɪfɔɹ," hi wɪspɝd. "aɪ wʌns sɛd ðəɾ aɪ dɪdn kɪl wɪmən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə laɪ. aɪ mɝɾɝd ə wʊmən lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ feɪst sɛmɝhɪdʒ. hɝ neɪm wɑz laɪæ. aɪ kɪld əɹ ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ.

"I've done it before," he whispered. "I once said that I didn't kill women, but it was a lie. I murdered a woman long before I faced Semirhage. Her name was Liah. I killed her in Shadar Logoth.

aɪ stʃɹʌk əɹ daʊn, ən aɪ kɔld ɪt mɝsi."

I struck her down, and I called it mercy."

hi tɝn tə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs pæləs bɪloʊ.

He turned to the fortress palace below.

"fɝɡɪv mi," hi sɛd, bʌɾ ɪt dɪdn sim dɝɛktəɾ ət mɪn, "fɔɹ kɔlɪŋ ðɪs mɝsi əz wɛl."

"Forgive me," he said, but it didn't seem directed at Min, "for calling this mercy as well."

sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɑsəbli bɹaɪt fɔɹmd ɪn ði ɛɹ bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ən mɪn kɹaɪɾ aʊt, bækɪŋ əweɪ. ði ɛɹ ɪtsɛlf sim tə wɔɹp, əz ɪf pʊlɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɹænd ɪn fɪɹ. dʌs blu fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn hɪm, ən ðə tʃɹiz ɡɹoʊnd, lɪt baɪ ðə bɹɪljənt waɪt laɪt, ðə paɪn niɾəlz ɹætlɪŋ laɪk ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən ɪnsɛks skɹæmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ. mɪn kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ meɪk aʊt ɹænd, oʊnli ə bleɪzɪŋ, bɹɪljən fɔɹs ə laɪt. pjʊɹ paʊɝ, ɡæðɝd, meɪkɪŋ ðə hɛɹz ɑn əɹ ɑɹmz ɹaɪz wɪð ðə fɔɹs ʌv ɪts nɛbjələs ɛnɝdʒi. ɪn ðət moʊmənt, ʃi fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi kəɾ ʌndɝstænd wʌt ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz. ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ, bɪfɔɹ hɝ, meɪɾ ɪnkɑɹnəɾ ɪn ðə mæn ɹænd ælθɹ.

Something impossibly bright formed in the air before him, and Min cried out, backing away. The air itself seemed to warp, as if pulling away from Rand in fear. Dust blew from the ground in a circle around him, and the trees groaned, lit by the brilliant white light, the pine needles rattling like a hundred thousand insects scrambling over one another. Min could no longer make out Rand, only a blazing, brilliant force of light. Pure power, gathered, making the hairs on her arms rise with the force of its nebulous energy. In that moment, she felt as if she could understand what the One Power was. It was there, before her, made incarnate in the man Rand al'Thor.

ən ðɛn, wɪð ə saʊn laɪk ə saɪ, hi ɹilist ɪt. ə kɑləm ə pjʊɹ waɪtnəs ɪksploʊɾəd fɹəm ɪm ən bɝn əkɹɔs ðə saɪlənt naɪt skaɪ, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz bɪloʊ ɪɾ ɪn ə weɪv. ɪt muvd əz kwɪk əz ə snæp ə ðə fɪŋɡɝz, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ðə wɔl ə ðə dɪstən fɔɹtʃɹəs. ðə stoʊnz keɪm əlaɪt, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ðə fɔɹs ə ði ɛnɝdʒi. ði ɪntaɪɝ fɔɹtʃɹəs ɡloʊd, tʃɹænsfɔɹmɪŋ ɪndə lɪvɪŋ laɪt, ən əmeɪzɪŋ, spɛktækjəlɝ pæləs ʌv ʌnədʌltɝeɪɾɪd ɛnɝdʒi. ɪt wɑz bjuɾəfəl.

And then, with a sound like a sigh, he released it. A column of pure whiteness exploded from him and burned across the silent night sky, illuminating the trees below it in a wave. It moved as quick as a snap of the fingers, striking the wall of the distant fortress. The stones came alight, as if they were breathing in the force of the energy. The entire fortress glowed, transforming into living light, an amazing, spectacular palace of unadulterated energy. It was beautiful.

ən ðən ɪt wɑz ɡɔn. bɝn fɹəm ðə lændskeɪp - ən ðə pæɾɝn - əz ɪf ɪt hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ðɛɹ.

And then it was gone. Burned from the landscape - and the Pattern - as if it had never been there.

ði ɪntaɪɝ fɔɹtʃɹəs, hʌnʒɹədz ə fiɾ ə stoʊn ən ɛvɹiwʌn u hæd lɪvd ɪn ɪt.

The entire fortress, hundreds of feet of stone and everyone who had lived in it.

sʌmθɪŋ hɪt mɪn, sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ə ʃɑkɪŋ weɪv ɪn ði ɛɹ. ɪt wɑzn ə fɪzɪkəl blæst, ən ɪt dɪdn meɪk əɹ stʌmbəl, bʌɾ ɪt twɪstəɾ əɹ ɪnsaɪdz əbaʊt. ðə fɔɹəst ɝaʊn əm - stɪl lɪt baɪ ðə ɡloʊɪŋ æksɛs ki ɪn ɹændz hænz - sim tə wɔɹp ən ʃeɪk. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf wɝ ɡɹoʊnɪŋ ɪn æɡəni.

Something hit Min, something like a shocking wave in the air. It wasn't a physical blast, and it didn't make her stumble, but it twisted her insides about. The forest around them - still lit by the glowing access key in Rand's hands - seemed to warp and shake. It was as if the world itself were groaning in agony.

ɪt snæp bæk, bʌt mɪn kəd stɪl fil ðət tɛnʃən. ɪn ðəɾ ɪnstənt, ɪt simd əz ɪf ðə vɛɹi sʌbstəns ʌv wɝl hæd bɪn nɪɹ tə bɹeɪkɪŋ.

It snapped back, but Min could still feel that tension. In that instant, it seemed as if the very substance of world had been near to breaking.

"wʌɾ əv jə dʌn?" nɪneɪiv wɪspɝd.

"What have you done?" Nynaeve whispered.

ɹænd dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ. mɪn kəd si hɪz feɪs əɡɛn, naʊ ðət ði ɪnɔɹməs kɑləm ə bɑlfaɪɝ hæd vænɪʃt, livɪŋ bɪhaɪn oʊnli ðə ɡloʊɪŋ æksɛs ki. hi wɑz ɪn ɛkstəsi, maʊθ əɡeɪp, ən i hɛl ði æksɛs ki əlɔf bɪfɔɹ hɪmsɛlf əz ɪf ɪn vɪktɝi. əɹ ɪn ɹɛvɝəns.

Rand didn't reply. Min could see his face again, now that the enormous column of balefire had vanished, leaving behind only the glowing access key. He was in ecstasy, mouth agape, and he held the access key aloft before himself as if in victory. Or in reverence.

ðən i ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ, aɪz oʊpənɪŋ waɪd, lɪps pɑɹɾəd əz ɪf i wɝ ʌndɝ ɡɹeɪt pɹɛʃɝ. ðə laɪt flæʃt wʌns, ðən ɪmiɾiətli vænɪʃt. ɔl bɪkeɪm dɑɹk. mɪn blɪŋkt ɪn ðə sʌɾən dɑɹknəs, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ əɹ aɪz tə ədʒʌst. ðə paʊɝfəl ɪmədʒ ə ɹænd sim bɝn ɪndə hɝ vɪʒən. hæɾ i ɹɪli dʌn wʌt ʃi θɔɾ i hæd? hæɾ i bɝn əweɪ ən ɪntaɪɝ fɔɹtʃɹəs wɪð bɑlfaɪɝ?

Then he gritted his teeth, eyes opening wide, lips parted as if he were under great pressure. The light flashed once, then immediately vanished. All became dark. Min blinked in the sudden darkness, trying to get her eyes to adjust. The powerful image of Rand seemed burned into her vision. Had he really done what she thought he had? Had he burned away an entire fortress with balefire?

ɔl ðoʊz pipəl. mɛn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fɹəm ðə hʌnt . . . wɪmən kæɹiɪŋ wɔɾɝ . . . soʊlʒɝz ɑn ðə wɔlz . . . ðə ɡɹumz aʊtsaɪd . . .

All those people. Men returning from the hunt . . . women carrying water . . . soldiers on the walls . . . the grooms outside . . .

ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn. bɝn fɹəm ðə pæɾɝn. kɪld. dɛd fɝɛvɝ. ðə hɔɹɝ ʌv ɪt meɪd mɪn stʌmbəl bæk, ən ʃi pɹɛst əɹ bæk əɡɛnst ə tʃɹi tə kip hɝsɛlf əpɹaɪt.

They were gone. Burned from the Pattern. Killed. Dead forever. The horror of it made Min stumble back, and she pressed her back against a tree to keep herself upright.

soʊ mɛni laɪvz, ɛndəɾ ɪn ən ɪnstənt. dɛd. dɪstʃɹɔɪd. baɪ ɹænd.

So many lives, ended in an instant. Dead. Destroyed. By Rand.

ə laɪɾ əpɪɹd fɹəm nɪneɪiv, ən mɪn tɝnd, siɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪluməneɪɾəd baɪ ðə wɔɹm, sɑft ɡloʊ ʌv ə ɡloʊb əbʌv əɹ hænd. hɝ aɪz simd ɔlmoʊst əfaɪɹ wɪð ə laɪɾ ə ðɛɹ oʊn. "ju ɑɹ aʊɾ ə kəntʃɹoʊl, ɹænd ælθɹ," ʃi dɪklɛɹd.

A light appeared from Nynaeve, and Min turned, seeing the Aes Sedai illuminated by the warm, soft glow of a globe above her hand. Her eyes seemed almost afire with a light of their own. "You are out of control, Rand al'Thor," she declared.

"aɪ də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn," hi sɛd, spikɪŋ naʊ fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz. hi saʊndəɾ ɪɡzɔstəd. "tɛs hɪm, nɪneɪiv."

"I do what must be done," he said, speaking now from the shadows. He sounded exhausted. "Test him, Nynaeve."

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"ðə ful," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪz əɹ kəmpʌlʃən stɪl ðɛɹ? ɪz ɡɹeɪndəlz tʌtʃ ɡɔn?"

"The fool," Rand said. "Is her Compulsion still there? Is Graendal's touch gone?"

"aɪ heɪt wʌt jə dʒʌs dɪd, ɹænd," nɪneɪiv snɑɹəld. "noʊ. 'heɪt' ɪzən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf. aɪ loʊð wʌt juv dʌn. wʌɾ əz hæpən tə ju?"

"I hate what you just did, Rand," Nynaeve snarled. "No. 'Hate' isn't strong enough. I loathe what you've done. What has happened to you?"

"tɛs hɪm!" ɹænd wɪspɝd, vɔɪs deɪnʒɝəs. "bɪfɔɹ kəndɛmɪŋ mi, lɛɾ əs fɝs dətɝmən ɪf maɪ sɪnz əv ətʃivd ɛniθɪŋ bɪɑn maɪ oʊn dæmneɪʃən."

"Test him!" Rand whispered, voice dangerous. "Before condemning me, let us first determine if my sins have achieved anything beyond my own damnation."

nɪneɪiv bɹiðd ɪn dipli, ðən ɡlænst ət ɹæmʃələn, hu wɑz stɪl hɛld ɪn ðə ɡɹɪp ə sɛvɹəl il meɪɾənz. nɪneɪiv ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən tʌtʃt ɪz fɔɹhɛd, kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ. "ɪts ɡɔn," ʃi sɛd.

Nynaeve breathed in deeply, then glanced at Ramshalan, who was still held in the grip of several Aiel Maidens. Nynaeve reached out and touched his forehead, concentrating. "It's gone," she said.

"ɪɹeɪst."

"Erased."

"ðɛn ʃiz dɛd," ɹænd sɛd fɹəm ðə dɑɹknəs.

"Then she is dead," Rand said from the darkness.

laɪt! mɪn θɔt, ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt hid dʌn. hi dɪdn juz ɹæmʃələn əz ə kɝiɝ, əɹ əz beɪt.

Light! Min thought, realizing what he'd done. He didn't use Ramshalan as a courier, or as bait.

hi juz ðə mæn əz ə weɪ ʌv pɹuvɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf ðət ɡɹeɪndəl wɑz dɛd. bɑlfaɪɝ bɝn sʌmwʌn aʊɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn kəmplitli, meɪkɪŋ ɪt soʊ ðət ðɛɹ moʊst ɹisən ækʃənz nɛvɝ əkɝd. ɹæmʃələn wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ vɪzəɾɪŋ ɡɹeɪndəl, bʌɾ əɹ kəmpʌlʃən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪɡzɪstəd. ɪn ə weɪ, ʃid bɪn kɪl bɪfɔɹ ɹæmʃələn hæd vɪzəɾəd hɝ.

He used the man as a way of proving to himself that Graendal was dead. Balefire burned someone out of the Pattern completely, making it so that their most recent actions never occurred. Ramshalan would remember visiting Graendal, but her Compulsion no longer existed. In a way, she'd been killed before Ramshalan had visited her.

mɪn fɛlt əɾ əɹ nɛk, wɛɹ ðə bɹuzəz ə ɹændz hæn ɑn əɹ nɛk hædn jɛt feɪɾəd.

Min felt at her neck, where the bruises of Rand's hand on her neck hadn't yet faded.

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd," ɹæmʃələn sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs nɪɹli ə skwik.

"I don't understand," Ramshalan said, his voice nearly a squeak.

"haʊ dʒju faɪt sʌmwʌn smɑɹɾɝ ðən jɝsɛlf?" ɹænd wɪspɝd. "ði ænsɝ ɪz sɪmpəl. jə meɪk əɹ θɪŋk ðət jə ɑɹ sɪɾɪŋ daʊn əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl fɹəm hɝ, ɹɛɾi tə pleɪ hɝ ɡeɪm. ðən jə pʌntʃ əɹ ɪn ðə feɪs əz hɑɹɾ əz jə kæn. juv sɝv mi wɛl, ɹæmʃələn. əl fɝɡɪv jə fəɹ boʊstɪŋ tə lɔɹdz vɪviən ən kɔlswɛl ðət jə kəd mənɪpjəleɪt mi haʊɛvɝ jə wɪʃt."

"How do you fight someone smarter than yourself?" Rand whispered. "The answer is simple. You make her think that you are sitting down across the table from her, ready to play her game. Then you punch her in the face as hard as you can. You have served me well, Ramshalan. I will forgive you for boasting to Lords Vivian and Callswell that you could manipulate me however you wished."

ɹæmʃələn slʌmpt ɪn ʃɑk, ən ðə meɪɾənz lɛɾ ɪm fɔl tə hɪz niz. "maɪ lɔɹd!" hi sɛd. "aɪ hæd tu mʌtʃ waɪn ðət naɪt, ən - "

Ramshalan slumped in shock, and the Maidens let him fall to his knees. "My Lord!" he said. "I had too much wine that night, and - "

"hʌʃ," ɹænd sɛd. "æz aɪ sɛd, juv sɝv mi wɛl ðɪs deɪ. əl nɑɾ ɛksəkjut ju. jəl faɪn ə vɪlədʒ tu deɪz' wɔk tə ðə saʊθ."

"Hush," Rand said. "As I said, you have served me well this day. I will not execute you. You will find a village two days' walk to the south."

wɪð ðæt, ɹænd tɝnd; tə mɪnz aɪz, hi wɑz dʒʌst ə ʃædoʊ ɹʌslɪŋ ɪn ðə fɔɹəst. hi wɔk tə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ən stɛp θɹu. mɪn hɝid tə fɑloʊ hɪm, ən nɪneɪiv dɪd laɪkwaɪz. ðə meɪɾənz keɪm læst, livɪŋ ɹæmʃələn nilɪŋ stupfaɪɾ ɪn ðə fɔɹəst. wən ðə læs meɪɾən wɑz θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ðə pɔɹɾəl slɪd kloʊzd, kʌɾɪŋ ɔf ðə saʊnz ə ɹæmʃələn wɪmpɝɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹk.

With that, Rand turned; to Min's eyes, he was just a shadow rustling in the forest. He walked to the gateway and stepped through. Min hurried to follow him, and Nynaeve did likewise. The Maidens came last, leaving Ramshalan kneeling stupefied in the forest. When the last Maiden was through the gateway, the portal slid closed, cutting off the sounds of Ramshalan whimpering in the dark.

"wʌt juv dʌn ɪz ən əbɑməneɪʃən, ɹænd ælθɹ," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ əz sun əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz kloʊzd. "ðɛɹ lʊk tə hæv bɪn dʌzənz, meɪbi hʌnʒɹədz, ʌv pipəl lɪvɪŋ ɪn ðət pæləs!"

"What you have done is an abomination, Rand al'Thor," Nynaeve said as soon as the gateway was closed. "There looked to have been dozens, maybe hundreds, of people living in that palace!"

"itʃ wʌn meɪɾ ɪndə ən ɪɾiət baɪ ɡɹeɪndəlz kəmpʌlʃən," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd. "ʃi nɛvɝ lɛts ɛniwʌn kloʊs tə hɝ wɪθaʊt dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ðɛɹ maɪn fɝst. ðə bɔɪ ʃi sɛn tə wɝk ðə dʒeɪl bɛɹli nu ə fɹækʃən ə ðə tɔɹtʃɝ moʊst ə hɝ pɛts ɹəsiv. ʃi livz əm wɪθaʊɾ əbɪləɾi tə θɪŋk əɹ ækt - ɔl ðeɪ kən də ɪz nil ən ədɔɹ hɝ, pɝhæps ɹʌn ɛɹənz əɾ əɹ kəmænd. aɪ dɪɾ əm ə feɪvɝ."

"Each one made into an idiot by Graendal's Compulsion," Rand replied. "She never lets anyone close to her without destroying their mind first. The boy she sent to work the jail barely knew a fraction of the torture most of her pets receive. She leaves them without ability to think or act - all they can do is kneel and adore her, perhaps run errands at her command. I did them a favor."

"ə feɪvɝ?" nɪneɪiv æskt. "ɹænd, jə juz bɑlfaɪɝ! ðeɪ wɝ bɝn aʊɾ ʌv ɛɡzɪstəns!"

"A favor?" Nynaeve asked. "Rand, you used balefire! They were burned out of existence!"

"æz aɪ sɛd," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd sɔfli. "ə feɪvɝ. səmtaɪmz, aɪ wɪʃ ðə seɪm blɛsɪŋ fəɹ maɪsɛlf. ɡʊd naɪt, nɪneɪiv. slip əz wɛl jə kæn, fəɹ əɹ taɪm ɪn ɑɹæd dumən ɪz əɾ ən ɛnd."

"As I said," Rand replied softly. "A favor. Sometimes, I wish the same blessing for myself. Good night, Nynaeve. Sleep as well you can, for our time in Arad Doman is at an end."

mɪn wɑtʃt ɪm ɡoʊ, wɪʃɪŋ tə spɹɪn æftɝ hɪm, bʌt hoʊldɪŋ hɝsɛlf bæk. wʌns i wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm ðə ɹum, nɪneɪiv slʌmpt ɪndə wʌn ə ðə ɹumz mɝun tʃɛɹz, saɪɪŋ ən linɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ əɡɛnst əɹ hænd.

Min watched him go, wishing to sprint after him, but holding herself back. Once he was gone from the room, Nynaeve slumped into one of the room's maroon chairs, sighing and leaning her head against her hand.

mɪn fɛlt laɪk duɪŋ ðə seɪm. əntɪl ðət moʊmənt, ʃi hædn ɹilaɪz dʒʌs haʊ dʒɹeɪnd ʃi wɑz.

Min felt like doing the same. Until that moment, she hadn't realized just how drained she was.

biɪŋ ɝaʊn ɹænd leɪtli dɪd ðət tə hɝ, ivən wən i wɑzn ɛnɡeɪdʒd ɪn æktɪvəɾiz əz tɛɹəbəl əz ðə wʌnz ðɪs naɪt.

Being around Rand lately did that to her, even when he wasn't engaged in activities as terrible as the ones this night.

"aɪ wɪʃ mɔɪɹeɪn wɝ hɪɹ," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd sɔfli, ðən fɹoʊz, əz ɪf sɝpɹaɪz tə hæv hɝd hɝsɛlf seɪ ðæt.

"I wish Moiraine were here," Nynaeve muttered softly, then froze, as if surprised to have heard herself say that.

"wi hæv tə də sʌmθɪŋ, nɪneɪiv," mɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"We have to do something, Nynaeve," Min said, looking at the Aes Sedai.

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd æbsənli. "meɪbi."

Nynaeve nodded absently. "Maybe."

"wʌt dʒju min baɪ ðæt?"

"What do you mean by that?"

"wɛl, wʌɾ ɪf hiz ɹaɪt?" nɪneɪiv æskt. "wʊl-hɛɾəd ful ðoʊ hi ɪz, wʌɾ ɪf i ɹɪli dʌz əv tə bi laɪk ðɪs tə wɪn? ði oʊld ɹænd kəd nɛvɝ əv dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ən ɪntaɪɝ fɔɹtʃɹəs fʊl ə pipəl tə kɪl wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən."

"Well, what if he's right?" Nynaeve asked. "Wool-headed fool though he is, what if he really does have to be like this to win? The old Rand could never have destroyed an entire fortress full of people to kill one of the Forsaken."

"ʌv kɔɹs i kʊdn hæv," mɪn sɛd. "hi stɪl kɛɹɾ əbaʊt kɪlɪŋ ðɛn! nɪneɪiv, ɔl ðoʊz laɪvz . . ."

"Of course he couldn't have," Min said. "He still cared about killing then! Nynaeve, all those lives . . ."

"æn haʊ mɛni pipəl wəd stɪl bi əlaɪv naʊ ɪf hid bɪn ðɪs ɹuθləs fɹəm ðə stɑɹt?"

"And how many people would still be alive now if he'd been this ruthless from the start?"

nɪneɪiv æskt, lʊkɪŋ əweɪ. "ɪf hid bɪn keɪpəbəl ə sɛndɪŋ ɪz fɑloʊɝz ɪndə deɪnʒɝ əz i dɪd ɹæmʃələn? ɪf hid bɪn eɪbəl tə stʃɹaɪk wɪθaʊt wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt hum i wəɾ əv tə kɪl? ɪf hiɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɪz tʃɹups ɪndə ɡɹeɪndəlz fɔɹtʃɹəs, hɝ fɑloʊɝz wʊɾə ɹɪzɪstɪd fənæɾɪkəli, ən ðeɪ wʊɾə ɛndəɾ ʌp dɛɾ ɛniweɪ. ən ʃi wəɾ əv ɪskeɪpt.

Nynaeve asked, looking away. "If he'd been capable of sending his followers into danger as he did Ramshalan? If he'd been able to strike without worrying about whom he would have to kill? If he'd ordered his troops into Graendal's fortress, her followers would have resisted fanatically, and they would have ended up dead anyway. And she would have escaped.

"ðɪs maɪt bi wʌt hiz tə bi. ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz nɪɹli əpɑn ʌs, mɪn. ðə læs bæɾəl! kən wi dɛɹ sɛn ə mæn tə faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn u woʊn sækɹəfaɪs fəɹ wʌt nidz tə bi dʌn?"

"This might be what he has to be. The Last Battle is nearly upon us, Min. The Last Battle! Can we dare send a man to fight the Dark One who won't sacrifice for what needs to be done?"

mɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "dɛɹ wi sɛn ɪm əz i ɪz, wɪð ðət lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪz? nɪneɪiv, hiz stɑp kɛɹɪŋ. nʌθɪŋ mæɾɝz tə hɪm ɛnimɔɹ bʌt dɪfiɾɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

Min shook her head. "Dare we send him as he is, with that look in his eyes? Nynaeve, he's stopped caring. Nothing matters to him anymore but defeating the Dark One."

"ɪzən ðət wʌt wi wɑn ɪm tə du?"

"Isn't that what we want him to do?"

"aɪ. . . ." ʃi stɑpt. "wɪnɪŋ woʊn bi wɪnɪŋ əɾ ɔl ɪf ɹænd bɪkʌmz sʌmθɪŋ əz bæɾ əz ðə fɔɹseɪkən . . . wi - "

"I. . . ." She stopped. "Winning won't be winning at all if Rand becomes something as bad as the Forsaken . . . We - "

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd," nɪneɪiv sɛd sʌɾənli. "laɪt bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ du, ən jəɹ ɹaɪt. aɪ dʒʌs doʊn laɪk ði ænsɝz ðoʊz kənkluʒənz ɑɹ ɡɪvɪŋ mi."

"I understand," Nynaeve said suddenly. "Light burn me, but I do, and you're right. I just don't like the answers those conclusions are giving me."

"wʌt kənkluʒənz?"

"What conclusions?"

nɪneɪiv saɪd. "ðæt kædzueɪn wɑz ɹaɪt," ʃi sɛd. nɪɹli ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ʃi æɾəd, "ɪnsʌfɝəbəl wʊmən." ʃi stʊɾ ʌp. "kʌm ɑn. wi nid tə faɪn əɹ ən dɪskʌvɝ wʌɾ əɹ plænz ɑɹ."

Nynaeve sighed. "That Cadsuane was right," she said. Nearly under her breath, she added, "Insufferable woman." She stood up. "Come on. We need to find her and discover what her plans are."

mɪn stʊd, dʒɔɪnɪŋ nɪneɪiv. "jɔɹ sɝɾən ʃiz plænz? ɹænd wɑz hɑɹʃ wɪð hɝ. meɪbi ʃiz dʒʌst steɪɪŋ wɪð əs tə wɑtʃ ɪm flaʊndɝ ən feɪl wɪθaʊt hɝ."

Min stood, joining Nynaeve. "You're certain she has plans? Rand was harsh with her. Maybe she's just staying with us to watch him flounder and fail without her."

"ʃi hæz plænz," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ɪf ðɛɹz wʌn θɪŋ wi kən kaʊn ɑn wɪð ðət wʊmən, ɪts ðət ʃiz skimɪŋ. wi dʒʌst əv tə kənvɪns əɹ tə lɛɾ əs ɪn ɑn ɪt."

"She has plans," Nynaeve said. "If there's one thing we can count on with that woman, it's that she's scheming. We just have to convince her to let us in on it."

"æn ɪf ʃi woʊnt?" mɪn æskt.

"And if she won't?" Min asked.

"ʃi wɪl," nɪneɪiv sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ɹændz ɡeɪtweɪ hæd splɪt ðə ɹʌɡ. "wʌns wi tɛl əɹ əbaʊt tənaɪt, ʃi wɪl. aɪ dɪslaɪk ðə wʊmən, ən aɪ səspɛkt ʃi ɹɪtɝnz ði ɪmoʊʃən, bʌt niðɝ ʌv əs kən hændəl ɹænd əloʊn." ʃi pɝst əɹ lɪps. "aɪ wɝi wi woʊn bi eɪbəl tə hændəl ɪm təɡɛðɝ.

"She will," Nynaeve said, looking at the place where Rand's gateway had split the rug. "Once we tell her about tonight, she will. I dislike the woman, and I suspect she returns the emotion, but neither of us can handle Rand alone." She pursed her lips. "I worry we won't be able to handle him together.

lɛts ɡoʊ."

Let's go."

mɪn fɑloʊd. "hændəl" ɹænd? ðət wɑz ənʌðɝ pɹɑbləm. nɪneɪiv ən kædzueɪn wɝ boʊθ soʊ kənsɝnd wɪð hænlɪŋ ðət ðeɪ feɪl tə si ðəɾ ɪt maɪt bi bɛs tə hɛlp ɪm ɪnstɛd. nɪneɪiv kɛɹd fəɹ ɹænd, bʌt ʃi sɔ hɪm əz ə pɹɑbləm tə bi fɪkst, ɹæðɝ ðən ə mæn ɪn nid.

Min followed. "Handle" Rand? That was another problem. Nynaeve and Cadsuane were both so concerned with handling that they failed to see that it might be best to help him instead. Nynaeve cared for Rand, but she saw him as a problem to be fixed, rather than a man in need.

ən soʊ mɪn əkʌmpənid ði ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊɾ ə ðə mænʃən. ðeɪ wɔkt ɪndə ðə dɑɹk kɔɹtʃjɑɹd  - nɪneɪiv meɪkɪŋ ə ɡloʊb ə laɪt - ən hɝiɾ ɝaʊn ðə bæk, pæs ðə steɪbəl ən təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪtkipɝz kɑɾədʒ. ðeɪ pæst əliviə ɑn ðə weɪ; ðə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn lʊk dɪsəpɔɪntɪd.

And so Min accompanied the Aes Sedai out of the mansion. They walked into the dark courtyard  - Nynaeve making a globe of light - and hurried around the back, past the stable and toward the gatekeeper's cottage. They passed Alivia on the way; the former damane looked disappointed.

laɪkli, ʃid bɪn tɝn əweɪ baɪ kædzueɪn ən ði ʌðɝz əɡɛn - əliviə spɛn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə tʃɹeɪn əɹ ɪn nu wivz.

Likely, she'd been turned away by Cadsuane and the others again - Alivia spent a great deal of time trying to get the Aes Sedai to train her in new weaves.

ðeɪ faɪnəli ɹitʃt ðə ɡeɪtkipɝz kɑɾədʒ - ət list, ðə ɡeɪtkipɝz kɑɾədʒ wɑz wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn əntɪl kædzueɪn pɹɪveɪld əpɑn ɪm tə muv aʊt. ɪt wɑz ə sɪŋɡəl-stɔɹi, θætʃ-ɹuf stʃɹʌktʃɝ ə peɪntəd jɛloʊ wʊd. laɪt ʃoʊn aʊt bɪtwin ðə ʃʌɾɝz ɑn ðə wɪndoʊz.

They finally reached the gatekeeper's cottage - at least, the gatekeeper's cottage was what it had been until Cadsuane prevailed upon him to move out. It was a single-story, thatch-roofed structure of painted yellow wood. Light shone out between the shutters on the windows.

nɪneɪiv stɛpt ʌp tə ðə fɹʌn ən nɑkt ɑn ðə stɝɾi oʊk dɔɹ; ɪt wɑz ænsɝd ʃɔɹtli baɪ mɛɹaɪs. "jɛs, tʃaɪld?" ðə ɡɹin æskt, əz ɪf ɪntɛnʃənəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡoʊd nɪneɪiv.

Nynaeve stepped up to the front and knocked on the sturdy oak door; it was answered shortly by Merise. "Yes, child?" the Green asked, as if intentionally trying to goad Nynaeve.

"aɪ hæv tə spik wɪð kædzueɪn," nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊld.

"I have to speak with Cadsuane," Nynaeve growled.

"kædzueɪn sədaɪ, ʃiz noʊ bɪznəs wɪð jə ɹaɪt naʊ," mɛɹaɪs sɛd, muvɪŋ tə kloʊz ðə kɑɾədʒ dɔɹ. "ɹɪtɝn təmɑɹoʊ, ən pɝhæps ʃɪl si ju."

"Cadsuane Sedai, she has no business with you right now," Merise said, moving to close the cottage door. "Return tomorrow, and perhaps she will see you."

"ɹæn ælθɹ dʒʌs bɝn ən ɪntaɪɝ pæləs fʊl ə pipəl fɹəm ɛɡzɪstəns wɪð bɑlfaɪɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə bi hɝd baɪ ðoʊz ɪnsaɪd ðə kɑɾədʒ. "aɪ wɑz wɪð hɪm."

"Rand al'Thor just burned an entire palace full of people from existence with balefire," Nynaeve said, loud enough to be heard by those inside the cottage. "I was with him."

mɛɹaɪs fɹoʊz.

Merise froze.

"lɛɾ əɹ ɪn," kædzueɪnz vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm ɪnsaɪd. ɹɪlʌktənli, mɛɹaɪs pʊld oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. ɪnsaɪd, mɪn sɔ kædzueɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɑn səm kʊʃənz ɑn ðə flɔɹ wɪð æmɪz, bɛɹ, məleɪn ən sɔɹɪliə. ðə fɹʌn ɹum - ðə meɪn ɹum - ʌv ðə kɑɾədʒ wɑz dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð ə sɪmpəl bɹaʊn ɹʌɡ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, moʊsli əbskjʊɹd baɪ ðə siɾəd wɪmən. ə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs bɝnd wɪð ə kɑm fleɪm ət ðə bæk, ðə wʊd nɪɹli kənsumd, ðə faɪɝ loʊ. ə stul sæɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, wɪð ə pɑɾ ə ti ɑn ɪt.

"Let her in," Cadsuane's voice said from inside. Reluctantly, Merise pulled open the door. Inside, Min saw Cadsuane sitting on some cushions on the floor with Amys, Bair, Melaine and Sorilea. The front room - the main room - of the cottage was decorated with a simple brown rug on the floor, mostly obscured by the seated women. A gray stone fireplace burned with a calm flame at the back, the wood nearly consumed, the fire low. A stool sat in the corner, with a pot of tea on it.

nɪneɪiv bɛɹli ɡeɪv ðə waɪz wʌnz ə ɡlæns. ʃi pʊʃt əɹ weɪ ɪndə ðə kɑɾədʒ, ən mɪn fɑloʊd mɔɹ hɛzɪɾəntli.

Nynaeve barely gave the Wise Ones a glance. She pushed her way into the cottage, and Min followed more hesitantly.

"tɛl əs ə ðɪs ɪvɛnt, tʃaɪld," sɔɹɪliə sɛd. "wi fɛl ðə wɝld wɔɹpɪŋ fɹəm hɪɹ, bʌt dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt hæd kɑzd ɪt. wi əsumd ɪt tə bi ðə dɑɹk wʌnz wɝk."

"Tell us of this event, child," Sorilea said. "We felt the world warping from here, but did not know what had caused it. We assumed it to be the Dark One's work."

"aɪl tɛl ju," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ðən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, "bʌɾ aɪ wɑnə bi ə pɑɹɾ ə jəɹ plænz."

"I'll tell you," Nynaeve said, then took a deep breath, "but I want to be a part of your plans."

"wi ʃæl si," kædzueɪn sɛd. "ɹɪleɪt jəɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns."

"We shall see," Cadsuane said. "Relate your experience."

mɪn tʊk ə siɾ ɑn ə wʊɾən stul ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum əz nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv əɹ əkaʊn ə nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ. ðə waɪz wʌnz lɪsənd, taɪt-lɪpt. kædzueɪn dʒʌs nɑɾəd əkeɪʒənəli. mɛɹaɪs, feɪs fʊl ə hɔɹɝ, ɹifɪl kʌps ə ti fɹəm ðə pɑɾ ɑn ðə stul - baɪ ðə smɛl ɪt wɑz tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ blæk - ðən sɛɾ ɪt tə hæŋ baɪ ðə faɪɝ. nɪneɪiv fɪnɪʃt, stɪl stændɪŋ.

Merise, face full of horror, refilled cups of tea from the pot on the stool - by the smell it was Tremalking black - then set it to hang by the fire. Nynaeve finished, still standing.

Oh, Rand, Min thought. This must be tearing you apart inside. But she could feel him through the bond; his emotions seemed very cold.

mɪn oʊnli hæf-lɪsənd. wʌtɛvɝ ðə plæn, sʌmwʌn wəd nid tə wɑtʃ aʊt fəɹ ɹænd. hɪz did ðɪs deɪ wəd bi dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ɪm ɪnsaɪd, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ i pɹoʊkleɪmd. ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv ʌðɝz wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt wʌɾ i wəd də ət ðə læs bæɾəl. ɪt wɑz əɹ dʒɑb tə ɡɛɾ ɪm tə ðət læs bæɾəl əlaɪv ən seɪn, wɪð ɪz soʊl ɪn wʌn pis.

Min only half-listened. Whatever the plan, someone would need to watch out for Rand. His deed this day would be destroying him inside, no matter what he proclaimed. sʌmhaʊ.

Somehow.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾieɪt

nuz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd "ɛɡwin, si ɹizən," sɪuən sɛd, feɪnli tʃɹænslusən kəz ə ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɹɪŋ ʃi hæd juz tə ɛntɝ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. News in Tel'aran'rhiod "Egwene, see reason," Siuan said, faintly translucent because of the ter'angreal ring she had used to enter Tel'aran'rhiod. "What good can you do, rotting in that cell? Elaida will see that you're never let free, not after what you said you did at that dinner." Siuan shook her head. "Mother, sometimes you just have to face truth. You can only repair a net so many times before you need to toss the thing aside and weave a new one."

ɛɡwin sæɾ ɑn ə θɹi-lɛɡəd stul ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum, ðə fɹʌn pɑɹɾ ʌv ə kɑblɝz ʃɑp.

Egwene sat on a three-legged stool in the corner of the room, the front part of a cobbler's shop.

She'd chosen the location at random, just in case, eschewing a location in the White Tower itself. The Forsaken knew that Egwene and the others walked the World of Dreams.

wɪð sɪuən, ɛɡwin kəd bi mɔɹ ɹɪlækst, mɔɹ əɹ ɹil sɛlf. ðə tu ʌv əm boʊθ ʌndɝstʊd ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz naʊ ði æmɪɝlɪn ən sɪuən əɹ lɛsɝ, bʌɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ðeɪ ʃɛɹɾ ə bɑnd. ə kɑmɝɑɾɝi du tə ðə steɪʃən ðeɪ boʊθ hæd fɪld. ðət bɑnd, stʃɹeɪnʒli, hæd tɝn ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ əkɪn tə fɹɛndʃɪp.

With Siuan, Egwene could be more relaxed, more her real self. The two of them both understood that Egwene was now the Amyrlin and Siuan her lesser, but at the same time, they shared a bond. At the moment, Egwene was nearly ready to strangle her friend. "We've been over this," she said firmly. "I cannot flee. Each day I spend imprisoned - but do not break - is another blow to Elaida's rule. If I disappear before her trial, it will undermine everything we've worked for!"

That was true. Egwene's bleeding had been from broken glass, not Elaida's stripes.

Tower law was intricate, and sorting out the proper punishments and interpretations could be complicated. The Three Oaths would have prevented Elaida from using the One Power as a weapon, and so Elaida must have thought that what she was doing wasn't a violation. Either she had gone farther than she'd planned, or she saw Egwene as a Darkfriend. She could argue for either position to defend herself; the latter would relieve her of the most guilt, but the former would be much easier to prove.
