sɪuən saɪd, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ fɝðɝ. ʃi sim tə hæv tu mʌtʃ nɝvəs ɛnɝdʒi tə sɪt, ən ɪɡnɔɹd ðə stul ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, ɪnstɛd gɑnə stæn baɪ ðə ʃɑp wɪndoʊ tə ɛɡwinz ɹaɪt.

Siuan sighed, but said nothing further. She seemed to have too much nervous energy to sit, and ignored the stool on the other side of the room, instead going to stand by the shop window to Egwene's right.

ðə kɑblɝz seɪlzɹum ʃoʊd saɪnz ʌv ɡɹeɪt tʃɹæfɪk. ə staʊt kaʊntɝ dɪvaɪɾəd ðə ɹum ɪn hæf, ðə wɔl bɪhaɪn pɑkəɾɪd wɪð dʌzənz ə ʃu-saɪz nʊks. ət taɪmz, moʊst ə ðiz wɝ stʌft wɪð stɝɾi wɝk ʃuz ə lɛðɝ əɹ kænvəs, leɪsəz hæŋɪŋ daʊn ðə fɹʌn əɹ bʌkəlz ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə fæntəm laɪɾ ə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. jɛɾ itʃ taɪm ɛɡwin ɡlænst ət ðə wɔl, ðə ʃuz hæd ʃɪftəd, səm vænɪʃɪŋ, ʌðɝz əpɪɹɪŋ. ðeɪ mʌs nɑt steɪ lɔŋ ɪn ðɛɹ kʌbihoʊlz ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld, fəɹ ðeɪ lɛft oʊnli veɪɡ ɪmədʒəz bɪhaɪn ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz.

The cobbler's salesroom showed signs of great traffic. A stout counter divided the room in half, the wall behind pocketed with dozens of shoe-sized nooks. At times, most of these were stuffed with sturdy work shoes of leather or canvas, laces hanging down the front or buckles gleaming in the phantom light of Tel'aran'rhiod. Yet each time Egwene glanced at the wall, the shoes had shifted, some vanishing, others appearing. They must not stay long in their cubbyholes in the real world, for they left only vague images behind in the world of dreams.

ðə fɹʌn hæf ə ðə ʃɑp wɑz kɹaʊɾəd wɪð stulz fəɹ kʌstəmɝz tə juz. ðə ʃuz ɑn ðə bæk wɔl wɝ ə dɪfɹən dɪzaɪnz ən pæɾɝnz, əlɔŋ wɪð tɛst ʃuz fəɹ saɪzɪŋ. ə pɝsən keɪm ɪndə ðə ʃɑp, tʃɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə saɪzɪŋ ʃuz, ðən pɪkt ə staɪl. ðə kɑblɝ - ɔɹ, laɪkli, hɪz əsɪstəns - wəd ðən kɹæft ə pɛɹ fəɹ leɪɾɝ pɪkʌp. ðə waɪd ɡlæs wɪndoʊz ət ðə fɹʌn pɹoʊkleɪm ðə neɪm ə ðə kɑblɝ ɪn waɪt peɪntəd lɛɾɝz tə bi neɪɝmən mæʃɪntə, ən ə smɔlɝ nʌmbɝ "θɹi" hæd bɪn peɪntəd bɪsaɪd ðə neɪm. ðɪs wɑz ðə θɝd dʒɛnɝeɪʃən ə mæʃɪntəs tə ɹʌn ðə ʃɑp. nɑɾ ənkɑmən əɾ ɔl əmʌŋ taʊnzfoʊk. ɪn fækt, ðə pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛɡwin ðət wɑz stɪl ɪnfluəns baɪ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz faʊn ɪɾ ɑd ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wəd kənsɪɾɝ livɪŋ ðɛɹ pɛɹəns tʃɹeɪd fəɹ ənʌðɝ, ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ ə θɝɾ əɹ fɔɹθ tʃaɪld.

The front half of the shop was crowded with stools for customers to use. The shoes on the back wall were of different designs and patterns, along with test shoes for sizing. A person came into the shop, tried on the sizing shoes, then picked a style. The cobbler - or, likely, his assistants - would then craft a pair for later pickup. The wide glass windows at the front proclaimed the name of the cobbler in white painted letters to be Naorman Mashinta, and a smaller number "three" had been painted beside the name. This was the third generation of Mashintas to run the shop. Not uncommon at all among townsfolk. In fact, the part of Egwene that was still influenced by the Two Rivers found it odd that anyone would consider leaving their parent's trade for another, unless they were a third or fourth child.

"naʊ ðət wiv dɛlt wɪð ði ɑbviəs," ɛɡwin sɛd, "wʌt nuz ɪz ðɛɹ?"

"Now that we've dealt with the obvious," Egwene said, "what news is there?"

"wɛl," sɪuən sɛd, linɪŋ ɑn ðə wɪndoʊ ən stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ət ði ɪɹəli ɛmpti tɑɹ vəlɑn stʃɹit.

"Well," Siuan said, leaning on the window and staring out at the eerily empty Tar Valon street.

"æn oʊld əkweɪntəns ə jʊɹz ɹisənli ɝaɪvd ɪn kæmp."

"An old acquaintance of yours recently arrived in camp."

"ɹɪli?" ɛɡwin æskt æbsənli. "hu?"

"Really?" Egwene asked absently. "Who?"

"ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd."

"Gawyn Trakand."

ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd. ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl! ɡɔɪn hæd saɪɾəd wɪð ɪleɪɾəz fækʃən dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɹɪbɛljən. hi wʊdn əv kʌm oʊvɝ tə ðə ɹɛbəl saɪd. hæɾ i bɪn kæptʃɝd? bʌt ðət wɑzn haʊ sɪuən hæd fɹeɪzd ɪt.

Egwene started. That was impossible! Gawyn had sided with Elaida's faction during the rebellion. He wouldn't have come over to the rebel side. Had he been captured? But that wasn't how Siuan had phrased it.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɛɡwin wɑz ə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ ɡɝl, kɑɾ ɪn ðə paʊɝ ə hɪz wɪspɝd pɹɑməsəz. ʃi mænədʒ tə kip əɹ fɔɹm lɑkt ɪndə ðəɾ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn, haʊɛvɝ, ən fɔɹst əɹ θɔts bæk tə ðə moʊmənt, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə bi kæʒəwəl əz ʃi ɹɪspɑndɪd. "ɡɔɪn?" ʃi æskt. "haʊ ɑd. aɪ wʊdn əv θɔt tə faɪn ɪm ðɛɹ."

For a moment, Egwene was a trembling girl, caught in the power of his whispered promises. She managed to keep her form locked into that of the Amyrlin, however, and forced her thoughts back to the moment, driving herself to be casual as she responded. "Gawyn?" she asked. "How odd. I wouldn't have thought to find him there."

sɪuən smaɪld. "ðæt wɑz naɪsli hændəld," ʃi sɛd. "ðoʊ jə pɔz tu lɔŋ, ən wən jə dɪɾ æsk fəɹ hɪm, jə wɝ oʊvɝli ənɪntʃɹəstəd. ðət meɪd jə izi tə ɹid."

Siuan smiled. "That was nicely handled," she said. "Though you paused too long, and when you did ask for him, you were overly uninterested. That made you easy to read."

"laɪt blaɪn ju," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ənʌðɝ tɛst? ɪz i ɹɪli ðɛɹ?"

"Light blind you," Egwene said. "Another test? Is he really there?"

"aɪ hoʊl tə ði oʊðz, θæŋk ju," sɪuən sɛd, əfɹʌntɪd. ɛɡwin wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju hu nu ðæt, əz ə ɹɪzʌlt ə hɝ stɪlɪŋ ən hilɪŋ, sɪuən hæd bɪn ɹilis fɹəm ðə θɹi oʊðz. bʌt, laɪk ɛɡwin, ʃi tʃoʊz nɑt tə laɪ ɛniweɪ.

"I hold to the oaths, thank you," Siuan said, affronted. Egwene was one of the few who knew that, as a result of her stilling and Healing, Siuan had been released from the Three Oaths. But, like Egwene, she chose not to lie anyway.

"iðɝ weɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd, "aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk ðət ðə taɪm fəɹ tɛstɪŋ mi hæz pæst."

"Either way," Egwene said, "I should think that the time for testing me has passed."

"ɛvɹiwʌn jə mit wɪl ɔlweɪz bi tɛstɪŋ ju, mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛd. "ju mʌs bi pɹipɛɹd fəɹ sɝpɹaɪzəz; əɾ ɛni moʊmən sʌmwʌn kəd θɹoʊ wʌn ət jə dʒʌs tə si haʊ jə ɹɪspɑnd."

"Everyone you meet will always be testing you, Mother," Siuan said. "You must be prepared for surprises; at any moment someone could throw one at you just to see how you respond."

"θæŋk ju," ɛɡwin sɛd koʊldli. "bʌɾ aɪ ɹɪli doʊnt nid ðə ɹimaɪndɝ."

"Thank you," Egwene said coldly. "But I really don't need the reminder."

"doʊn ju?" sɪuən sɛd. "saʊnz ə lɪɾəl laɪk sʌmθɪŋ ɪleɪɾə wəd seɪ."

"Don't you?" Siuan said. "Sounds a little like something Elaida would say."

"ðæts ənfɛɹ!"

"That's unfair!"

"pɹuv ɪt," sɪuən sɛd smʌɡli.

"Prove it," Siuan said smugly.

ɛɡwin fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə bi kɑm. sɪuən wɑz ɹaɪt. bɛɾɝ tə teɪk ði ædvaɪs, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən ɪt wɑz ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs, ðən tə kəmpleɪn. "ju ɑɹ ɹaɪt, ʌv kɔɹs," ɛɡwin sɛd, smuðɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs əkɹɔs əɹ niz əz ʃi ɔlsoʊ smuðd ðə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən fɹəm əɹ feɪs. "tɛl mi mɔɹ ʌv ɡɔɪnz ɝaɪvəl."

Egwene forced herself to be calm. Siuan was right. Better to take the advice, particularly when it was good advice, than to complain. "You are right, of course," Egwene said, smoothing out her dress across her knees as she also smoothed the frustration from her face. "Tell me more of Gawyn's arrival."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ," sɪuən kənfɛst. "aɪ ɹɪli ʃʊɾə mɛnʃən ɪt jɛstɝdeɪ, bʌɾ əɹ miɾɪŋ wɑz kʌt ʃɔɹt." ðeɪ wɝ miɾɪŋ mɔɹ ɔfən naʊ - itʃ naɪɾ ʌv ɛɡwinz ɪmpɹɪzənmənt -  bʌt jɛstɝdeɪ sʌmθɪŋ hæɾ əweɪkən sɪuən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd fɪnɪʃt tɔkɪŋ. ə bʌbəl ʌv ivəl ɪn ðə ɹɛbəl kæmp, ʃi hæd ɹipɔɹɾəd, ɪnvɑlvɪŋ tɛns kʌmɪŋ əlaɪv ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stʃɹæŋɡəl pipəl. θɹi hæd daɪd, wʌn ə ðɛm ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"I don't know much more," Siuan confessed. "I really should have mentioned it yesterday, but our meeting was cut short." They were meeting more often now - each night of Egwene's imprisonment -  but yesterday something had awakened Siuan before they had finished talking. A bubble of evil in the rebel camp, she had reported, involving tents coming alive and trying to strangle people. Three had died, one of them Aes Sedai.

"ɛniweɪ," sɪuən kəntɪnjud, "ɡɔɪn hæzən sɛd mʌtʃ ðəɾ aɪ kəd hɪɹ. aɪ θɪŋk hiz hɪɹ kəz i hɝd ðət jə wɝ kæptʃɝd. hi ɝaɪvd wɪð ə spɛktækjəlɝ flɝi, bʌt naʊ hi steɪz ɪn bɹaɪnz kəmæn poʊst, vɪzəɾɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɛɡjəlɝli. hiz mʌlɪŋ oʊvɝ sʌmθɪŋ; kips gɑnə spik tə ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn."

"Anyway," Siuan continued, "Gawyn hasn't said much that I could hear. I think he's here because he heard that you were captured. He arrived with a spectacular flurry, but now he stays in Bryne's command post, visiting the Aes Sedai regularly. He's mulling over something; keeps going to speak to Romanda and Lelaine."

"ðæts tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ."

"That's troubling."

"wɛl, ðeɪ ɑɹ ði ɑbviəs paʊɝ ɪn kæmp," sɪuən sɛd. "seɪv wən ʃɛɹiəm ən ði ʌðɝz kən ɹɛntʃ səm əθɔɹəɾi əweɪ. θɪŋz hævənt ɡɔn wɛl wɪθaʊt ju; ðə kæmp nidz liɾɝʃɪp.

"Well, they are the obvious power in camp," Siuan said. "Save when Sheriam and the others can wrench some authority away. Things haven't gone well without you; the camp needs leadership.

æktʃəli , wi kɹeɪv ɪt, əz ə stɑɹvɪŋ fɪʃɝmæn kɹeɪvz ə kætʃ. ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ ə pipəl ʌv ɔɹɾɝ, aɪ səpoʊz. ɪt - "

Actually, we crave it, as a starving fisherman craves a catch. Aes Sedai are a people of order, I suppose. It - "

ʃi stɑp hɝsɛlf. laɪkli, ʃi hæd bɪn əbaʊt tə bʊli ɛɡwin əɡɛn tə æksɛpt ɹɛskju. ʃi ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin, ðən kəntɪnjud. "wɛl, ɪɾəl bi ɡʊd fəɹ əs wən jə ɹɪtɝn, mʌðɝ. ðə lɔŋɡɝ jə steɪ əweɪ, ðə stʃɹɔŋɝ ðə fækʃənz bɪkʌm. jə kən ɔlmoʊst si ðə laɪnz daʊn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kæmp naʊ. ɹoʊmændə ɑn wʌn saɪd, ləleɪn ɑn ði ʌðɝ, wɪð ə ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ slaɪs ðət dʌznt wɑnə teɪk saɪdz."

She stopped herself. Likely, she had been about to bully Egwene again to accept rescue. She glanced at Egwene, then continued. "Well, it will be good for us when you return, Mother. The longer you stay away, the stronger the factions become. You can almost see the lines down the middle of the camp now. Romanda on one side, Lelaine on the other, with a shrinking slice that doesn't want to take sides."

" wi kænɑɾ əfɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ dɪvɪʒən," ɛɡwin sɛd. "nɑɾ əmʌŋ aʊɝsɛlvz; wɪv tə pɹuv stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɪleɪɾə."

" We cannot afford another division," Egwene said. "Not among ourselves; we have to prove stronger than Elaida."

"æt list əɹ splɪts ɑɹən əlɔŋ ðə laɪnz ʌv ədʒɑ," sɪuən sɛd dɪfɛnsɪvli.

"At least our splits aren't along the lines of Ajah," Siuan said defensively.

"fækʃənz ən bɹeɪks," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌp. "ɪnfaɪɾɪŋ ən skwɑbəlɪŋ. wəɹ bɛɾɝ ðən ðɪs, sɪuən. tɛl ðə hɔl ðəɾ aɪ wɪʃ tə mit wɪð ðɛm. pɝhæps ɪn tu deɪz. təmɑɹoʊ, jə ən aɪ ʃəd miɾ əɡɛn."

"Factions and breaks," Egwene said, getting up. "Infighting and squabbling. We are better than this, Siuan. Tell the Hall that I wish to meet with them. Perhaps in two days. Tomorrow, you and I should meet again."

sɪuən nɑɾəd hɛzɪɾəntli. "vɛɹi wɛl."

Siuan nodded hesitantly. "Very well."

ɛɡwin aɪd hɝ. "ju θɪŋk ɪɾ ənwaɪz?"

Egwene eyed her. "You think it unwise?"

"noʊ," sɪuən sɛd. "aɪ wɝi əbaʊt haʊ hɑɹd jəɹ pʊʃɪŋ jɝsɛlf. ði æmɪɝlɪn nidz tə lɝn tə ɹæʃən əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ; səm ɪn jəɹ pleɪs əv feɪl nɑt kəz ðeɪ læk ðə kəpæsəɾi fəɹ ɡɹeɪtnəs, bʌt kəz ðeɪ stʃɹɛtʃt ðət kəpæsəɾi tu θɪn, spɹɪntɪŋ wən ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv wɔkt."

"No," Siuan said. "I worry about how hard you're pushing yourself. The Amyrlin needs to learn to ration her strength; some in your place have failed not because they lacked the capacity for greatness, but because they stretched that capacity too thin, sprinting when they should have walked."

ɛɡwin ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt ðət sɪuən hɝsɛlf hæd spɛn mʌtʃ ə hɝ tɛnjɝ əz æmɪɝlɪn spɹɪntɪŋ əɾ ə bɹeɪknɛk spid. bʌɾ ɪt kəd vɛɹi wɛl bi ɑɹɡjud ðət sɪuən hæd stʃɹɛtʃt hɝsɛlf tu θɪn, ən hæd fɔlən əz ə ɹɪzʌlt. hu bɛɾɝ tə spik ɑn ðə deɪnʒɝz ə sətʃ æktɪvəɾiz ðən wʌn u hæd bɪn bɝn baɪ ðɛm soʊ dipli?

Egwene refrained from pointing out that Siuan herself had spent much of her tenure as Amyrlin sprinting at a breakneck speed. But it could very well be argued that Siuan had stretched herself too thin, and had fallen as a result. Who better to speak on the dangers of such activities than one who had been burned by them so deeply?

"ði ædvaɪs ɪz əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd, dɔɾɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌt ɹɪli, ðəɹ ɪz lɪɾəl tə wɝi əbaʊt.

"The advice is appreciated, daughter," Egwene said. "But really, there is little to worry about.

maɪ deɪz ɑɹ spɛn ɪn sɑlətud, wɪð ði əkeɪʒənəl biɾɪŋ tə pɹəvaɪd spaɪs. ðiz miɾɪŋz ət naɪt hɛlp mi sɝvaɪv." ʃi ʃɪvɝd, ɡlænsɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm sɪuən, aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ təwɔɹd ðə dɝɾi, veɪkən stʃɹit.

My days are spent in solitude, with the occasional beating to provide spice. These meetings at night help me survive." She shivered, glancing away from Siuan, out the window toward the dirty, vacant street.

"ɪz ɪt dɪfəkəl tə ɛndʒjʊɹ?" sɪuən æsk sɔfli.

"Is it difficult to endure?" Siuan asked softly.

"ðə sɛl ɪz nɛɹoʊ ɪnʌf fəɹ mi tə tʌtʃ ɑpəzət wɔlz ət wʌns," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn ɪzən vɛɹi lɔŋ, iðɝ. wən aɪ laɪ daʊn, aɪ hæv tə bɛn maɪ niz tə fɪt. aɪ kæn stænd, sɪns ðə silɪŋ ɪz soʊ loʊ ɪt meɪks mi stup, ən aɪ kæn sɪt wɪθaʊt peɪn, fəɹ ðeɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hil mi bɪtwin biɾɪŋz. ðə stʃɹɔ ɪz oʊld ən ɪtʃəz. ðə dɔɹ ɪz θɪk ən ðə kɹæks doʊn əlaʊ ɪn mʌtʃ laɪt. aɪ wɑzn əwɛɹ ðət ðə taʊɝ hæd sɛlz sətʃ əz ðɪs wʌn." ʃi ɡlæns bæk ət sɪuən. "wʌns aɪm əphɛl fʊli əz æmɪɝlɪn, ðɪs ɹum ən ɛni laɪk ɪɾəl bi ɹimuvd, ðə dɔɹz ɹɪpt aʊɾ ən ðə sɛlz ðɛmsɛlvz fɪld wɪð bɹɪks ən mɔɹɾɝ."

"The cell is narrow enough for me to touch opposite walls at once," Egwene said. "And isn't very long, either. When I lie down, I have to bend my knees to fit. I can't stand, since the ceiling is so low it makes me stoop, and I can't sit without pain, for they no longer Heal me between beatings. The straw is old and itches. The door is thick and the cracks don't allow in much light. I wasn't aware that the Tower had cells such as this one." She glanced back at Siuan. "Once I am upheld fully as Amyrlin, this room and any like it will be removed, the doors ripped out and the cells themselves filled with bricks and mortar."

sɪuən nɑɾəd. "wil meɪk sɝɾən ʌv ɪt."

Siuan nodded. "We'll make certain of it."

ɛɡwin tɝn əweɪ əɡɛn, ən noʊɾəst wɪð ʃeɪm ðət ʃid lɛɾ əɹ ɡaʊn ʃɪf tə ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ ʌv ən il meɪɾən, kəmplit wɪð spɪɹz ən baʊ əɾ əɹ bæk. ʃi fɔɹs ðə kloʊðɪŋ bæk, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ. "noʊ pɝsən ʃəd bi kɛpt ɪn sətʃ ə mænɝ," ʃi sɛd, "nɑɾ ivən. . . ."

Egwene turned away again, and noticed with shame that she'd let her gown shift to the cadin'sor of an Aiel Maiden, complete with spears and bow at her back. She forced the clothing back, taking a deep breath. "No person should be kept in such a manner," she said, "not even. . . ."

sɪuən fɹaʊn əz ɛɡwin tʃɹeɪld ɔf. "wʌt wɑz ðæt?"

Siuan frowned as Egwene trailed off. "What was that?"

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɪt dʒʌst əkɝd tə mi. ðɪs ɪz wʌɾ ɪt mʌst əv bɪn laɪk fəɹ ɹænd. noʊ, wɝs. ðə stɔɹiz seɪ hi wɑz lɑkt ɪn ə bɑks smɔlɝ ðən maɪ sɛl. ət list aɪ kən spɛn pɑɹɾ ə ði ivnɪŋz tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð ju. hi hæd noʊbɑdi. hi wɑz wɪθaʊt ðə bɪlif ðəɾ ɪz biɾɪŋz mɛn sʌmθɪŋ." laɪt sɛn ðət ʃi dɪdn əv tə ɛndʒjʊɹ əz lɔŋ əz i hæd. hɝ ɪmpɹɪzənmən hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ə fju deɪz soʊ fɑɹ.

Egwene shook her head. "It just occurred to me. This is what it must have been like for Rand. No, worse. The stories say he was locked in a box smaller than my cell. At least I can spend part of the evenings chatting with you. He had nobody. He was without the belief that his beatings meant something." Light send that she didn't have to endure as long as he had. Her imprisonment had only been a few days so far.

sɪuən fɛl saɪlənt.

Siuan fell silent.

"ɹəɡɑɹdləs," ɛɡwin sɛd, "aɪ hæv tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪz, maɪ bɑɾi ɪz kæptɪv, bʌt maɪ soʊl ɪz fɹi ət naɪt. ən itʃ deɪ aɪ ɛndʒjʊɹ ɪz ənʌðɝ pɹuf ðəɾ ɪleɪɾəz wɪl ɪz nɑt lɔ. ʃi kænɑt bɹeɪk mi. hɝ səpɔɹt fɹəm ði ʌðɝz ɪz ɪɹoʊɾɪŋ. tʃɹʌs mi."

"Regardless," Egwene said, "I have Tel'aran'rhiod. During the days, my body is captive, but my soul is free at night. And each day I endure is another proof that Elaida's will is not law. She cannot break me. Her support from the others is eroding. Trust me."

sɪuən nɑɾəd. "vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. "ju ɑɹ æmɪɝlɪn."

Siuan nodded. "Very well," she said, rising. "You are Amyrlin."

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪ æm," ɛɡwin sɛɾ æbsənli.

"Of course I am," Egwene said absently.

"noʊ, ɛɡwin," sɪuən sɛd. "aɪ mɛn ðət fɹəm ðə hɑɹt."

"No, Egwene," Siuan said. "I meant that from the heart."

ɛɡwin tɝnd, sɝpɹaɪzd. "bʌt juv ɔlweɪz bɪlivd ɪn mi!"

Egwene turned, surprised. "But you've always believed in me!"

sɪuən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

Siuan raised an eyebrow.

"æt list," ɛɡwin sɛd, "fɹʌm fɛɹli nɪɹ ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ."

"At least," Egwene said, "from fairly near the beginning."

"aɪ ɔlweɪz bɪliv jə hæd pətɛnʃəl," sɪuən kɝɛktəd. "wɛl, juv fʊlfɪld ɪt. səm ʌv ɪɾ ət list. ɪnʌf ʌv ɪt. haʊɛvɝ ðɪs stɔɹm bloʊz θɹu, juv pɹuvən wʌn θɪŋ. jə dɪzɝv ðə pleɪs jə hoʊld. laɪt, ɡɝl, jə meɪ ɛn ʌp biɪŋ ðə bɛst æmɪɝlɪn ðɪs wɝld əz noʊn ðɪs saɪɾ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɹeɪn!" ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "æn ðæts nɑɾ ən izi θɪŋ fəɹ mi tə ədmɪt, maɪn ju."

"I always believed you had potential," Siuan corrected. "Well, you've fulfilled it. Some of it at least. Enough of it. However this storm blows through, you've proven one thing. You deserved the place you hold. Light, girl, you may end up being the best Amyrlin this world has known this side of Artur Hawkwing's reign!" She hesitated. "And that's not an easy thing for me to admit, mind you."

ɛɡwin tʊk sɪuənz ɑɹmz, smaɪlɪŋ. waɪ, sɪuən ɔlmoʊs lʊk tɪɹi-aɪd wɪð pɹaɪd! "ɔl aɪ dɪd wɑz ɡɛt maɪsɛlf lɑkt ɪn ə sɛl."

Egwene took Siuan's arms, smiling. Why, Siuan almost looked teary-eyed with pride! "All I did was get myself locked in a cell."

"æn jə dɪɾ ɪt laɪk ən æmɪɝlɪn, ɛɡwin," sɪuən sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ ʃəd bi ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk. səm ʌv əs kæn spɛn əɹ deɪz ɹɪlæksɪŋ ðə weɪ jə kæn. wi nid ɹil slip, ʌðɝwaɪz wɝ laɪkli tə fɔl ʌnkɑnʃəs ɪn əɹ wɑʃwɔɾɝ." ʃi ɡɹɪməst, ɹilisɪŋ hɝsɛlf fɹəm ɛɡwinz hænz.

"And you did it like an Amyrlin, Egwene," Siuan said. "But I should be getting back. Some of us can't spend our days relaxing the way you can. We need real sleep, otherwise we're likely to fall unconscious in our washwater." She grimaced, releasing herself from Egwene's hands.

"ju kəd dʒʌs tɛl ɪm tə - "

"You could just tell him to - "

"naʊ, əl əv nʌn ə ðæt," sɪuən sɛd, wæɡɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ əɾ ɛɡwin. hæd ʃi fɝɡɑɾən ðət ʃid dʒʌs bɪn kəmpləmɛntɪŋ ɛɡwinz stætʃɝ əz ən æmɪɝlɪn? "aɪ ɡeɪv maɪ wɝd, ən əl bi fɪʃ ɡʌts bɪfɔɹ əl bɹeɪk ɪt."

"Now, I'll have none of that," Siuan said, wagging a finger at Egwene. Had she forgotten that she'd just been complimenting Egwene's stature as an Amyrlin? "I gave my word, and I'll be fish guts before I'll break it."

ɛɡwin blɪŋkt. "aɪ wʊdn dʒɹim ə meɪkɪŋ ju," ʃi sɛd, kʌvɝɪŋ ə smaɪl əz ʃi noʊɾəst ðət sɪuənz ʃæɾoʊi fɔɹm naʊ hæɾ ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd ɹɪbən ɪn ɪts hɛɹ. "ɔf wɪð ju, ðɛn."

Egwene blinked. "I wouldn't dream of making you," she said, covering a smile as she noticed that Siuan's shadowy form now had a bright red ribbon in its hair. "Off with you, then."

sɪuən nɑɾəd ʃɑɹpli, ðən sæt daʊn ən kloʊzd əɹ aɪz. ʃi feɪɾəd sloʊli fɹəm tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd.

Siuan nodded sharply, then sat down and closed her eyes. She faded slowly from Tel'aran'rhiod.

ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɛɹiə wɛɹ sɪuən hæd bɪn. ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli taɪm tə ɹɪtɝn tə nɔɹməl dʒɹimɪŋ, lɛɾɪŋ əɹ maɪn ɹɪstɔɹ ɪtsɛlf. bʌt ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɝ nɔɹməl dʒɹimz wəd bi ə stɛp təwɔɹd weɪkɪŋ, ən wən ʃi woʊk ʃi wəd faɪn oʊnli ðət kɹæmp dʌnʒən ən ɪts stʌfi dɑɹknəs.

Egwene hesitated, watching the area where Siuan had been. It was probably time to return to normal dreaming, letting her mind restore itself. But returning to her normal dreams would be a step toward waking, and when she woke she would find only that cramped dungeon and its stuffy darkness.

ʃi lɔŋ tə steɪ ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. ʃi θɔɾ ə vɪzəɾɪŋ ɪleɪnz dʒɹimz tə æsk fəɹ ə miɾɪŋ . . . bʌt noʊ, ðət wəd teɪk tu mʌtʃ taɪm, əsumɪŋ ɪleɪn kəd meɪk əɹ dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɝk. ʃi ɹɛɹli kʊd, ðiz deɪz.

She longed to stay in the World of Dreams just a little longer. She thought of visiting Elayne's dreams to ask for a meeting . . . but no, that would take too much time, assuming Elayne could make her dream ter'angreal work. She rarely could, these days.

ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf stɛpɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn, ðə kɑblɝz ʃɑp vænɪʃɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ.

She found herself stepping away from Tar Valon, the cobbler's shop vanishing around her.

ʃi əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp. ə fulɪʃ pleɪs tə vɪzət, pɝhæps. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz əɹ fɔɹseɪkən ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, ðeɪ kəd vɛɹi wɛl bi stʌɾiɪŋ ðɪs kæmp ən lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, mʌtʃ əz ɛɡwin səmtaɪmz vɪzəɾəd ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd tə sɝtʃ fəɹ kluz ɑn ɪleɪɾəz plænz. bʌɾ ɛɡwin niɾəd tə kʌm hɪɹ. ʃi dɪdn kwɛstʃən waɪ; ʃi sɪmpli fɛl ðəɾ ɪt wɑz tʃɹu.

She appeared in the rebel Aes Sedai camp. A foolish place to visit, perhaps. If there were Darkfriends or Forsaken in the World of Dreams, they could very well be studying this camp and looking for information, much as Egwene sometimes visited the Amyrlin's study in Tel'aran'rhiod to search for clues on Elaida's plans. But Egwene needed to come here. She didn't question why; she simply felt that it was true.

ðə stʃɹits ə ðə kæmp wɝ mʌɾi, wɔɹn ɪn ɹʌts fɹəm pæsɪŋ wæɡənz. wʌns dʒʌst ə fild, ði ɛɹiə hæd bɪn əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪd baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən tɝn ɪndə . . . sʌmθɪŋ. pɑɹɾ ə pleɪs ʌv wɔɹ, wɪð bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz kæmpt ɪn ə ɹɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm. pɑɹt taʊn, ðoʊ noʊ taʊn hæɾ ɛvɝ boʊstəd sətʃ ə kɑmpləmən ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd. pɑɹt mɑnjəmən tə ðə wiknəs ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

The streets of the camp were muddy, worn in ruts from passing wagons. Once just a field, the area had been appropriated by the Aes Sedai and turned into . . . something. Part a place of war, with Bryne's soldiers camped in a ring about them. Part town, though no town had ever boasted such a complement of Aes Sedai, novices and Accepted. Part monument to the weakness of the White Tower.

ɛɡwin wɔk ðə kæmps meɪn θɝoʊfɛɹ, wɛɹ widz hæd bɪn tʃɹæmpəl tə mʌd, ðən mʌd wɔɹn ɪndə ə ɹoʊd. wɔkweɪz laɪn ɪt, ən tɛns kʌvɝd ðə flæt læn bɪɑnd. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ pipəl, oʊnli ði əkeɪʒənəl fliɾɪŋ ɡlɪmps ʌv ə slipɝ u hæd stʌmbəld ɪndə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. hɪɹ, ə bɹif flæʃ ʌv ə wʊmən ɪn ə faɪn ɡɹin ɡaʊn. ə dʒɹimɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, pɝhæps, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz dʒʌst əz laɪkli tə bi ə sɝvɪŋ meɪɾ ɪmædʒənɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə bi ə kwin. ðɛɹ, ə wʊmən ɪn waɪt - ə wʊmən wɪð stʃɹɪŋi blɑn hɛɹ u wɑz fɑɹ tu oʊl tə bi ə nɑvəs. ðət noʊ lɔŋɡɝ mæɾɝd. ðə nɑvəs bʊk ʃəɾ əv lɔŋ əɡoʊ bɪn oʊpən tə ɔl. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz tu wik tə tɝn daʊn ɛni sɔɹs ə stʃɹɛŋkθ.

Egwene walked the camp's main thoroughfare, where weeds had been trampled to mud, then mud worn into a road. Walkways lined it, and tents covered the flat land beyond. There were no people, only the occasional fleeting glimpse of a sleeper who had stumbled into Tel'aran'rhiod. Here, a brief flash of a woman in a fine green gown. A dreaming Aes Sedai, perhaps, though it was just as likely to be a serving maid imagining herself to be a queen. There, a woman in white - a woman with stringy blond hair who was far too old to be a novice. That no longer mattered. The novice book should have long ago been opened to all. The White Tower was too weak to turn down any source of strength.

boʊθ wɪmən wɝ ɡɔn ɔlmoʊst əz kwɪkli əz ðeɪ əpɪɹd. fju dʒɹimɝz steɪd lɔŋ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd; tə ɹɪmeɪn lɔŋɡɝ, wʌn niɾəd iðɝ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ skɪl laɪk ɛɡwinz əɹ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil laɪk ðə ɹɪŋ sɪuən juzd. ðəɹ wɑz ə θɝd weɪ. ɡɛɾɪŋ kɑɾ ʌp ɪn ə lɪvɪŋ naɪtmɛɹ. ðəɹ wɝ nʌn ə ðə læɾɝ əbaʊt, θæŋk ðə laɪt.

Both women were gone almost as quickly as they appeared. Few dreamers stayed long in Tel'aran'rhiod; to remain longer, one needed either a particular skill like Egwene's or a ter'angreal like the ring Siuan used. There was a third way. Getting caught up in a living nightmare. There were none of the latter about, thank the Light.

ðə kæmp sim stʃɹeɪnʒ tə bi soʊ dɪzɝɾɪd. ɛɡwin hæd lɔŋ sɪns stɑp biɪŋ ənnɝv baɪ ði ɪɹi læk ə pipəl ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. bʌt ðɪs kæmp wɑz dɪfɹən sʌmhaʊ. ɪt lʊkt əz ə wɔɹ kæmp maɪɾ æftɝ ɔl ə ðə soʊlʒɝz hæd bɪn slɔɾɝd ɑn ðə bæɾəlfild. dɪzɝɾɪd, jɛt stɪl ə bænɝ tə pɹoʊkleɪm ðə laɪvz ə ðoʊz u hæɾ ɑkjəpaɪɾ ɪt. ɛɡwin fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi kəd si ðə dɪvɪʒən ðət sɪuən hæd tɔkt əbaʊt, tɛns klʌmp təɡɛðɝ laɪk bʌntʃəz ə spɹaʊɾɪŋ flaʊɝz.

The camp seemed strange to be so deserted. Egwene had long since stopped being unnerved by the eerie lack of people in Tel'aran'rhiod. But this camp was different somehow. It looked as a war camp might after all of the soldiers had been slaughtered on the battlefield. Deserted, yet still a banner to proclaim the lives of those who had occupied it. Egwene felt as if she could see the division that Siuan had talked about, tents clumped together like bunches of sprouting flowers.

wɪð ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz ɹimuvd, ʃi kəd si ðə pæɾɝnz ən ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ðeɪ bɪspoʊk. ɛɡwin maɪt dɪnaʊns ɪleɪɾə fəɹ ðə ɹɪfs əmʌŋ ði ədʒəz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌɾ ɛɡwinz oʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fɹæktʃɝ əz wɛl. wɛl, θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd hɑɹdli ɡæðɝ wɪθaʊt tu ʌv əm meɪkɪŋ ən əlaɪəns. ɪt wɑz hɛlθi tə hæv ðə wɪmən plænɪŋ ən pɹipɛɹɪŋ; ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz wən ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə ɹəɡɑɹɾ ʌðɝz ə ðɛɹ kaɪn əz ɛnəmiz, ɹæðɝ ðən dʒʌst ɹaɪvəlz.

With individuals removed, she could see the patterns and the troubles they bespoke. Egwene might denounce Elaida for the rifts among the Ajahs in the White Tower, but Egwene's own Aes Sedai were beginning to fracture as well. Well, three Aes Sedai could hardly gather without two of them making an alliance. It was healthy to have the women planning and preparing; the trouble was when they began to regard others of their kind as enemies, rather than just rivals.

sɪuən wɑz ɹaɪt, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. ɛɡwin kəd nɑt spɛn mʌtʃ mɔɹ taɪm sɛɾɪŋ əɹ hoʊps ɑn ɹɛkənsɪlieɪʃən. wʌɾ ɪf ðə waɪt taʊɝ dɪdn ənsiɾ ɪleɪɾə? wʌɾ ɪf, dɪspaɪɾ ɛɡwinz pɹəɡɹɛs, ðə ɹɪfs bɪtwin ði ədʒəz nɛvɝ hild? wʌt ðɛn? ɡoʊ tə wɔɹ?

Siuan was right, unfortunately. Egwene could not spend much more time setting her hopes on reconciliation. What if the White Tower didn't unseat Elaida? What if, despite Egwene's progress, the rifts between the Ajahs never healed? What then? Go to war?

ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ ɑpʃən, wʌn ðət nʌn ə ðɛm hæd bɹɔɾ ʌp: ðəɾ ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ɑn ɹɛkənsɪlieɪʃən pɝmənənli. sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ə sɛkənd waɪt taʊɝ. ɪt wəd min livɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɹoʊkən, pɝhæps fɝɛvɝ. ɛɡwin ʃʌɾɝəd ət ðə pɹɑspɛkt, ən əɹ skɪn ɪtʃt, ɹɪbɛlɪŋ əɡɛns ðə θɔt.

There was another option, one that none of them had brought up: that of giving up on reconciliation permanently. Setting up a second White Tower. It would mean leaving the Aes Sedai broken, perhaps forever. Egwene shuddered at the prospect, and her skin itched, rebelling against the thought.

bʌt wʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs? ʃi hæd tə kənsɪɾɝ ðə ɹæməfəkeɪʃənz, ən ʃi faʊn əm dɔntɪŋ. haʊ kəd ðeɪ ɛnkɝɪdʒ ðə kɪn əɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz tə taɪ ðɛmsɛlvz tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ nɑt junəfaɪd? ðə tu waɪt taʊɝz wəd bɪkʌm əpoʊz fɔɹsɪz, kənfjuzɪŋ ðə liɾɝz ə mɛn əz ɹaɪvəl æmɪɝlənz tʃɹaɪd tə juz neɪʃənz fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn pɝpəsəz. ælaɪz ən ɛnəmiz əlaɪk wəd luz ðɛɹ ɑ ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən kɪŋz vɛɹi wɛl maɪt stɑɹɾ ʌp ðɛɹ oʊn sɛntɝz fəɹ wɪmən tæləntəɾ ɪn tʃænəlɪŋ.

But what if she had no other choice? She had to consider the ramifications, and she found them daunting. How could they encourage the Kin or the Wise Ones to tie themselves to the Aes Sedai if the Aes Sedai themselves were not unified? The two White Towers would become opposed forces, confusing the leaders of men as rival Amyrlins tried to use nations for their own purposes. Allies and enemies alike would lose their awe of the Aes Sedai, and kings very well might start up their own centers for women talented in channeling.

ɛɡwin stil hɝsɛlf, wɔkɪŋ ɑn ðə mʌɾi ɹoʊd, ðə tɛns əlɔŋ ðə weɪ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, ðɛɹ flæps oʊpən, ðən kloʊzd, ðən oʊpən əɡɛn ɪn ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪfɛmɝəl weɪ ʌv ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz. ɛɡwin fɛl ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl əpɪɹ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, tu hɛvi, əz ɪf woʊvən wɪð lɛd weɪts.

Egwene steeled herself, walking on the muddy road, the tents along the way changing, their flaps open, then closed, then open again in the strange ephemeral way of the World of Dreams. Egwene felt the Amyrlin's stole appear around her neck, too heavy, as if woven with lead weights.

ʃi wəd bɹɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɝ saɪd. ɪleɪɾə wəd fɔl. bʌɾ ɪf nɑt . . . ðən ɛɡwin wəd də wʌt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə pɹəzɝv ðə pipəl, ən ðə wɝld, ɪn ðə feɪs ə tɑɹmən ɡdən.

She would bring the White Tower Aes Sedai to her side. Elaida would fall. But if not . . . then Egwene would do what was necessary in order to preserve the people, and the world, in the face of Tarmon Gai'don.

ʃi stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə kæmp, ðə tɛns, ɹʌts, ən ɛmpti stʃɹits vænɪʃɪŋ. əɡɛn, ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən wɛɹ əɹ maɪnd wəd teɪk hɝ. tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz ðɪs weɪ - lɛɾɪŋ nid dɝɛkt əɹ - kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs, bʌɾ ɪt kəɾ ɔlsoʊ bi vɛɹi ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ. ɪn ðɪs keɪs, ʃi lʊk nɑt fəɹ ən əbdʒɛkt, bʌt fəɹ nɑlədʒ. wʌd ʃi nid tə noʊ, wʌd ʃi nid tə si?

She stepped away from the camp, the tents, ruts, and empty streets vanishing. Again, she wasn't certain where her mind would take her. Traveling in the World of Dreams this way - letting need direct her - could be dangerous, but it could also be very illuminating. In this case, she looked not for an object, but for knowledge. What did she need to know, what did she need to see?

hɝ sɝaʊndɪŋz blɝd, ðən snæp bæk stʃɹeɪt. ʃi stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə smɔl kæmp, faɪɝ smoʊldɝɪŋ ɪn ə faɪɹɛpɪt bɪfɔɹ hɝ, ə taɪni tʌŋ ə smoʊk kɝlɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ. ðət wɑz ɑd.

Her surroundings blurred, then snapped back straight. She stood in the middle of a small camp, fire smoldering in a firepit before her, a tiny tongue of smoke curling toward the sky. That was odd.

faɪɝ wɑz juʒəwəli tu fliɾɪŋ tə ɹəflɛkt ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ æktʃəwəl fleɪmz, dɪspaɪt ðə smoʊk ən ði ɔɹənʒ ɡloʊ wɔɹmɪŋ ðə smuð ɹɪvɝstoʊnz ðət ɹɪŋ ðə pɪt. ʃi ɡlænst ʌpwɝd, təwɔɹd ðə tu-dɑɹk, stɔɹmi skaɪ. ðət saɪlən stɔɹm wɑz ənʌðɝ ɪɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾi fəɹ ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪkʌm soʊ kɑmən leɪtli ðət ʃi hɑɹdli noʊɾəst ɪɾ ɛnimɔɹ. kəɾ ɛniθɪŋ bi kɔld ɹɛɡjəlɝ fəɹ ðɪs pleɪs?

Fire was usually too fleeting to reflect in Tel'aran'rhiod. There were no actual flames, despite the smoke and the orange glow warming the smooth riverstones that ringed the pit. She glanced upward, toward the too-dark, stormy sky. That silent storm was another irregularity for the World of Dreams, though it had become so common lately that she hardly noticed it anymore. Could anything be called regular for this place?

wɪð ʃɑk, ʃi noʊɾəst kʌlɝfəl wæɡənz ɝaʊn hɝ, ɡɹin, ɹɛd, ɔɹənʒ ən jɛloʊ. hæd ðeɪ bɪn ðəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ? ʃi wɑz ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ klɪɹɪŋ sɛɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ə fɔɹəst ə fæntəm waɪɾ æspən.

With shock, she noticed colorful wagons around her, green, red, orange and yellow. Had they been there a moment before? She was in a large clearing set inside a forest of phantom white aspen.

ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ wɑz θɪk, wɛɹ spɪnli waɪld ɡɹæs poʊk fɪŋɡɝz aʊɾ ɪn dʒæɡd pætʃəz. ən oʊvɝɡɹoʊn ɹoʊd miændɝd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz tə hɝ ɹaɪt; ðə kʌlɝfəl wæɡənz sæɾ ɪn ə ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ. bɹaɪt peɪns kʌlɝd ðə saɪdz ə ðə bɑksi vihɪkəlz, wɪtʃ hæd ɹufs ən wɔlz laɪk taɪni bɪldɪŋz. ɑksən dɪd nɑt ɹəflɛkt ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, bʌt pleɪts, kʌps ən spunz əpɪɹd, ðən vænɪʃt fɹəm pleɪsəz bɪsaɪd ðə faɪɹɛpɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə sits ə ðə wæɡənz.

The underbrush was thick, where spindly wild grass poked fingers out in jagged patches. An overgrown road meandered through the trees to her right; the colorful wagons sat in a ring around the fire. Bright paints colored the sides of the boxy vehicles, which had roofs and walls like tiny buildings. Oxen did not reflect in the World of Dreams, but plates, cups and spoons appeared, then vanished from places beside the firepit or on the seats of the wagons.

ɪt wɑz ə kæmp ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, ðə tuætɑn. waɪ ðɪs pleɪs? ɛɡwin wɔkt aɪdli ɝaʊn ðə faɪɹɛpɪt, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə wæɡənz, ðə koʊts ə peɪn kɛp fɹɛʃ ən fɹi ʌv kɹæks əɹ steɪnz.

It was a camp of the Traveling People, the Tuatha'an. Why this place? Egwene walked idly around the firepit, looking at the wagons, the coats of paint kept fresh and free of cracks or stains.

ðɪs kæɹəvæn wɑz mʌtʃ smɔlɝ ðən ðə wʌn ʃi ən pɛɹɪn hæd vɪzəɾəd soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd mʌtʃ ðə seɪm fil. ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ ðə fluts ən dʒɹʌmz, kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪmædʒən ðoʊz flɪkɝz fɹəm ðə faɪɹɛpɪt tə bi ðə ʃædoʊz ə dænsɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən. dɪd ðə tuætɑn stɪl dæns, wɪð ðət skaɪ soʊ fʊl ʌv ɡlum, ðə wɪnz soʊ fʊl ʌv ɪl nuz? wʌt pleɪs wɑz ðəɹ fəɹ əm ɪn ə wɝl pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ wɔɹ? tʃɹɑləks kɛɹd nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif. dɪd ðɪs ɡɹup ə tuætɑn sik tə haɪd fɹəm ðə læs bæɾəl?

This caravan was much smaller than the one she and Perrin had visited so long ago, but it had much the same feel. She could almost hear the flutes and drums, could almost imagine those flickers from the firepit to be the shadows of dancing men and women. Did the Tuatha'an still dance, with that sky so full of gloom, the winds so full of ill news? What place was there for them in a world preparing for war? Trollocs cared nothing for the Way of the Leaf. Did this group of Tuatha'an seek to hide from the Last Battle?

ɛɡwin sɛɾəld hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə saɪd stɛps ʌv ə wæɡən, wɪtʃ wɑz tɝn tə feɪs ðə nɪɹbaɪ faɪɹɛpɪt.

Egwene settled herself on the side steps of a wagon, which was turned to face the nearby firepit.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi lɛɾ əɹ ɡaʊn tʃeɪnʒ tə ðəɾ ʌv ə sɪmpəl, wʊlən tu ɹɪvɝz dʒɹɛs ʌv ɡɹin, mʌtʃ laɪk ðə wʌn ʃid wɔɹn dʊɹɪŋ əɹ taɪm vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl. ʃi stɛɹɾ ɪndə ðoʊz nɑnəɡzɪstən fleɪmz, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ən pɑndɝɪŋ. wʌt hæd bɪkʌm ʌv ɛɹæm, ɹən ən ilə? laɪkli ðeɪ wɝ seɪf sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ə kæmp dʒʌs laɪk ðɪs wʌn, weɪɾɪŋ tə si wʌt tɑɹmən ɡdən wəd də tə ðə wɝld. ɛɡwin smaɪld, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðoʊz deɪz wən ʃid flɝɾɪd ən dænst wɪð ɛɹæm bɪniθ pɛɹɪnz skaʊlɪŋ dɪsəpɹuvəl. ðət hæd bɪn ə sɪmpəlɝ taɪm; ðoʊ ðə tɪŋkɝz ɔlweɪz simd eɪbəl tə meɪk ə sɪmpəlɝ taɪm fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz.

For a moment, she let her gown change to that of a simple, woolen Two Rivers dress of green, much like the one she'd worn during her time visiting the Traveling People. She stared into those nonexistent flames, remembering and pondering. What had become of Aram, Raen and Ila? Likely they were safe somewhere in a camp just like this one, waiting to see what Tarmon Gai'don would do to the world. Egwene smiled, thinking of those days when she'd flirted and danced with Aram beneath Perrin's scowling disapproval. That had been a simpler time; though the Tinkers always seemed able to make a simpler time for themselves.

jɛs, ðɪs ɡɹup wəd stɪl dæns. ðeɪ wəd dæns ɹaɪɾ ʌp əntɪl ðə deɪ wən ðə pæɾɝn bɝn əweɪ, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðeɪ faʊn ðɛɹ sɔŋ, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt tʃɹɑləks ɹævɪdʒ ðə wɝld əɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪt.

Yes, this group would still dance. They would dance right up until the day when the Pattern burned away, whether or not they found their song, whether or not Trollocs ravaged the world or the Dragon Reborn destroyed it.

hæd ʃi lɛt hɝsɛlf luz saɪɾ ə ðoʊz θɪŋz wɪtʃ wɝ moʊs pɹɛʃəs? waɪ dɪd ʃi faɪt soʊ hɑɹd tə sɪkjʊɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ? fəɹ paʊɝ? fəɹ pɹaɪd? əɹ kəz ʃi fɛlt ɪt ɹɪli wɑz bɛs fəɹ ðə wɝld?

Had she let herself lose sight of those things which were most precious? Why did she fight so hard to secure the White Tower? For power? For pride? Or because she felt it really was best for the world?

wɑz ʃi gɑnə sʌk hɝsɛlf dʒɹaɪ əz ʃi fɔt ðɪs bæɾəl? ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən - ɔɹ, wʊɾə tʃoʊzən - ðə ɡɹin ən nɑt ðə blu. ðə dɪfɝəns wɑzn dʒʌs ðət ʃi laɪk ðə weɪ ðə ɡɹinz stʊɾ ʌp ən fɔt; ʃi θɔt ðət ðə bluz wɝ tu foʊkəst. laɪf wɑz mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ðən ə sɪŋɡəl kɑz. laɪf wɑz əbaʊt lɪvɪŋ. əbaʊt dʒɹimɪŋ, læfɪŋ ən dænsɪŋ.

Was she going to suck herself dry as she fought this battle? She had chosen - or, would have chosen - the Green and not the Blue. The difference wasn't just that she liked the way the Greens stood up and fought; she thought that the Blues were too focused. Life was more complicated than a single cause. Life was about living. About dreaming, laughing and dancing.

ɡɔɪn wɑz ɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp. ʃi sɛd ðət ʃid tʃoʊzən ðə ɡɹin fəɹ ɪts əɡɹɛsɪv dɪtɝməneɪʃən - ɪt wɑz ðə bæɾəl ədʒɑ. bʌɾ ə mɔɹ sikɹət, mɔɹ ɑnəst, pɑɹɾ ə hɝsɛlf ədmɪɾəd ðət ɡɔɪn wɑz ə moʊɾəveɪʃən fəɹ əɹ dɪsɪʒən əz wɛl. əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, mɛɹiɪŋ wʌnz wɔɹɾɝ wɑz kɑmən. ɛɡwin wəɾ əv ɡɔɪn fəɹ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ. ən əɹ hʌzbənd.

Gawyn was in the Aes Sedai camp. She said that she'd chosen the Green for its aggressive determination - it was the Battle Ajah. But a more secret, more honest, part of herself admitted that Gawyn was a motivation for her decision as well. Among the Green Ajah, marrying one's Warder was common. Egwene would have Gawyn for her Warder. And her husband.

ʃi lʌv hɪm. ʃi wəd bɑn hɪm. ðoʊz dɪzaɪɝz ə hɝ hɑɹt wɝ lɛs ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ðə feɪɾ ə ðə wɝld, tʃɹu, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

She loved him. She would bond him. Those desires of her heart were less important than the fate of the world, true, but they were still important.

ɛɡwin ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə stɛps əz əɹ dʒɹɛs tʃɹænsfɔɹm bæk ɪndə ðə waɪɾ ən sɪlvɝ ɡaʊn ə ði æmɪɝlɪn. ʃi tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən lɛt ðə wɝld ʃɪft.

Egwene rose from the steps as her dress transformed back into the white and silver gown of the Amyrlin. She took a step forward and let the world shift.

ʃi stʊd bɪfɔɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ʃi tɝn əɹ aɪz haɪ, ɹʌnɪŋ əm əlɔŋ ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə dɛləkət - jɛt stɪl paʊɝfəl - waɪt spaɪɹ. ðoʊ ðə skaɪ bʌbəld ɪn blæk tɝmɔɪl, sʌmθɪŋ kæst ə ʃædoʊ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ, ən ɪt fɛl dɝɛkli ɑn ɛɡwin. wɑz ðɪs ə vɪʒən ə səm sɔɹt? ðə taʊɝ dwɔɹf hɝ, ən ʃi fɛlt ɪts weɪt, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp hɝsɛlf. pʊʃɪŋ ɑn ðoʊz wɔlz, kipɪŋ əm fɹəm kɹækɪŋ ən tʌmbəlɪŋ.

She stood before the White Tower. She turned her eyes high, running them along the length of the delicate - yet still powerful - white spire. Though the sky bubbled in black turmoil, something cast a shadow from the Tower, and it fell directly on Egwene. Was this a vision of some sort? The Tower dwarfed her, and she felt its weight, as if she were holding it up herself. Pushing on those walls, keeping them from cracking and tumbling.

ʃi stʊd fəɹ ə lɔŋ waɪl ðɛɹ, skaɪ bɔɪlɪŋ, ðə taʊɝz pɝfək spaɪɹ θɹoʊɪŋ ɪts ʃædoʊ daʊn ɑn ɛɡwin. ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp əɾ ɪts pik, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪɾ ɪf ɪt wɑz taɪm tə dʒʌs lɛɾ ɪt fɔl.

She stood for a long while there, sky boiling, the Tower's perfect spire throwing its shadow down on Egwene. She stared up at its peak, trying to decide if it was time to just let it fall.

noʊ, ʃi θɔɾ əɡɛn. noʊ, nɑt kwaɪt jɛt. ə fju mɔɹ deɪz.

No, she thought again. No, not quite yet. A few more days.

ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, ðən oʊpən əm tə blæknəs. hɝ bɑɾi sʌɾənli ɪksploʊɾəd wɪð peɪn, hɝ bæksaɪd paʊndɪd ɹɔ fɹəm ðə stʃɹæp, hɝ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz kɹæmp fɹəm biɪŋ fɔɹs tə laɪ kɝld ɪn ðə smɔl ɹum. ɪt smɛld ʌv oʊl stʃɹɔ ən moʊld, ən ʃi nu ðəɾ ɪf əɹ noʊz hædn bɪn juz tə ɪt, ʃi wʊɾə smɛl ðə stɛntʃ ə hɝ oʊn ənwɑʃt bɑɾi əz wɛl. ʃi staɪfəld ə ɡɹoʊn - ðəɹ wɝ wɪmən aʊtsaɪd, ɡɑɹɾɪŋ əɹ ən meɪnteɪnɪŋ əɹ ʃild. ʃi wʊdn lɛɾ əm hɪɹ əɹ ɔfɝ kəmpleɪnt, nɑɾ ivən ɪn ðə fɔɹm ʌv ə ɡɹoʊn.

She closed her eyes, then opened them to blackness. Her body suddenly exploded with pain, her backside pounded raw from the strap, her arms and legs cramped from being forced to lie curled in the small room. It smelled of old straw and mold, and she knew that if her nose hadn't been used to it, she would have smelled the stench of her own unwashed body as well. She stifled a groan - there were women outside, guarding her and maintaining her shield. She wouldn't let them hear her offer complaint, not even in the form of a groan.

ʃi sæɾ ʌp, wɛɹɪŋ ðə seɪm nɑvəs dʒɹɛs ðət ʃid wɔɹn tə ɪleɪɾəz dɪnɝ pɑɹɾi. ðə slivz ə ðə dʒɹɛs wɝ stɪf wɪð dʒɹaɪd blʌd, ən ðɪs kɹækt əz ʃi muvd, skɹeɪpɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ skɪn. ʃi wɑz pɑɹtʃt; ðeɪ nɛvɝ ɡeɪv əɹ ɪnʌf wɔɾɝ. bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt kəmpleɪn. noʊ jɛlz, noʊ kɹaɪz, noʊ bɛɡɪŋ. ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə sɪɾ ʌp dɪspaɪt ðə peɪn, smaɪlɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf ət haʊ ɪt fɛlt. ʃi kɹɔst əɹ lɛɡz, ðən lin bæk ən - wʌn baɪ wʌn - stʃɹɛtʃt ðə mʌsəlz ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz. ðən ʃi stʊɾ ən stupt oʊvɝ, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ əɹ bæk ən ʃoʊldɝz. faɪnəli, ʃi leɪ daʊn ɑn əɹ bæk ən stʃɹɛtʃt əɹ lɛɡz ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ, kɹɪŋɪŋ əz ðeɪ kəmpleɪnd. ʃi niɾəd tə ɹɪmeɪn lɪmbɝ. peɪn wɑz nʌθɪŋ.

She sat up, wearing the same novice dress that she'd worn to Elaida's dinner party. The sleeves of the dress were stiff with dried blood, and this cracked as she moved, scraping against her skin. She was parched; they never gave her enough water. But she did not complain. No yells, no cries, no begging. She forced herself to sit up despite the pain, smiling to herself at how it felt. She crossed her legs, then leaned back and - one by one - stretched the muscles in her arms. Then she stood and stooped over, stretching her back and shoulders. Finally, she lay down on her back and stretched her legs up into the air, cringing as they complained. She needed to remain limber. Pain was nothing.

nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl kəmpɛɹd wɪð ðə deɪnʒɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz ɪn.

Nothing at all compared with the danger the White Tower was in.

ʃi sæt bæk daʊn, kɹɔs-lɛɡəd, ən tʊk dip bɹɛθs, ɹɪpiɾɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə bi lɑkt ɪn ðɪs ɹum. ʃi kəɾ ɪskeɪp ɪf ʃi wɪʃt, bʌt ʃi ɹɪmeɪnd. baɪ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ʃi ʌndɝmaɪn ɪleɪɾə. baɪ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ʃi pɹuv ðət səm wəd nɑt baʊ ən kwaɪətli æksɛp ðə fɔl ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðɪs ɪmpɹɪzənmən mɛn sʌmθɪŋ.

She sat back down, cross-legged, and took deep breaths, repeating to herself that she wanted to be locked in this room. She could escape if she wished, but she remained. By remaining she undermined Elaida. By remaining she proved that some would not bow and quietly accept the fall of the White Tower. This imprisonment meant something.

ðə wɝdz, ɹɪpiɾɪd ɪn əɹ hɛd, hɛlp steɪv ɔf ðə pænɪk ət kənsɪɾɝɪŋ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ deɪ wɪðɪn ðɪs sɛl. wʌt wəd ʃi hæv dʌn wɪθaʊt ðə naɪtli dʒɹimz tə kip əɹ seɪn? əɡɛn, ʃi θɔɾ ə pʊɹ ɹænd, lɑkt əweɪ. ʃi ən i ʃɛɹd sʌmθɪŋ naʊ. ə kɪnʃɪp bɪɑn ə kɑmən tʃaɪldhʊɾ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ðeɪ hæd boʊθ sʌfɝɾ ɪleɪɾəz pʌnɪʃməns. ən ɪt hædn bɹoʊkən iðɝ ə ðɛm.

The words, repeated in her head, helped stave off the panic at considering yet another day within this cell. What would she have done without the nightly dreams to keep her sane? Again, she thought of poor Rand, locked away. She and he shared something now. A kinship beyond a common childhood in the Two Rivers. They had both suffered Elaida's punishments. And it hadn't broken either of them.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də bʌt weɪt. ɝaʊnd nun, ðeɪ wəɾ oʊpən ðə dɔɹz ən dʒɹæɡ hɝ aʊt tə bi biɾən. ɪt wʊdn bi sɪlviænə hu dɪd ðə pʌnɪʃɪŋ. ɡɪvɪŋ ðə biɾɪŋz wɑz sin əz ə ɹɪwɔɹd, kɑmpənseɪʃən tə ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz fəɹ hævɪŋ tə spɛn ɔl deɪ sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dʌnʒənz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ hɝ.

There was nothing to do but wait. Around noon, they would open the doors and drag her out to be beaten. It wouldn't be Silviana who did the punishing. Giving the beatings was seen as a reward, compensation to the Red sisters for having to spend all day sitting in the dungeons guarding her.

æftɝ ðə biɾɪŋ, ɛɡwin wəd ɡoʊ bæk ɪn ðə sɛl ən bi ɡɪvən ə boʊl ə teɪsləs ɡɹuɪl. deɪ æftɝ deɪ ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm. bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt bɹeɪk, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli nɑt waɪl ʃi kəd spɛn ðə naɪts ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ɪn fækt, ɪn mɛni weɪz, ðoʊz wɝ əɹ deɪz - spɛn fɹi ən æktɪv - waɪl ðiz wɝ əɹ naɪts, ɪn ɪnæktɪv dɑɹknəs. ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf ðæt.

After the beating, Egwene would go back in the cell and be given a bowl of tasteless gruel. Day after day it was the same. But she would not break, particularly not while she could spend the nights in Tel'aran'rhiod. In fact, in many ways, those were her days - spent free and active - while these were her nights, in inactive darkness. She told herself that.

ðə mɔɹnɪŋ pæst sloʊli. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, aɪɝn kiz klæŋkt əz wʌn tɝn ɪn ði eɪntʃən lɑk. ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən ə pɛɹ ə slɛndɝ ɹɛd sɪstɝz stʊɾ aʊtsaɪd, bɛɹli sɪləwɛts, ðə laɪt soʊ ʌnfəmɪljɝ tə ɛɡwin ðət ʃi kʊdn meɪk aʊt ðɛɹ fitʃɝz. ðə ɹɛdz ɡɹæbd əɹ ɹʌfli baɪ ði ɑɹmz, ðoʊ ʃi nɛvɝ ɹɪzɪstɪd. ðeɪ pʊld əɹ aʊɾ ən θɹu hɝ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ʃi hɝd ðə stʃɹæp əz wʌn slæpt ɪɾ əɡɛnst əɹ hæn ɪn æntɪsəpeɪʃən, ən ɛɡwin stil hɝsɛlf fəɹ ðə bloʊz. ðeɪ wəd hɪɹ əɹ læf, dʒʌst əz ðeɪ hæɾ ɛvɹi deɪ bɪfɔɹ.

The morning passed slowly. Eventually, iron keys clanked as one turned in the ancient lock. The door opened, and a pair of slender Red sisters stood outside, barely silhouettes, the light so unfamiliar to Egwene that she couldn't make out their features. The Reds grabbed her roughly by the arms, though she never resisted. They pulled her out and threw her to the ground. She heard the strap as one slapped it against her hand in anticipation, and Egwene steeled herself for the blows. They would hear her laugh, just as they had every day before.

"weɪt," ə vɔɪs sɛd.

"Wait," a voice said.

ði ɑɹmz hoʊldɪŋ ɛɡwin daʊn ɡɹu stɪf. ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd, tʃik pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə koʊl taɪl flɔɹ. ðət vɔɪs . . . ɪt hæd bɪn keɪɾɝinz.

The arms holding Egwene down grew stiff. Egwene frowned, cheek pressed against the cold tile floor. That voice . . . it had been Katerine's.

sloʊli, ðə sɪstɝz hoʊldɪŋ ɛɡwin ɹɪlæks ðɛɹ ɡɹɪps, pʊlɪŋ əɹ tə hɝ fit. ʃi blɪŋkt əɡɛns ðə bleɪzɪŋ laɪɾ ə ðə læmps tə faɪn keɪɾɝin stændɪŋ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, hɝ ɑɹmz foʊldəd. "ʃi ɪz tə bi ɹilist," ðə ɹɛd sɛd, saʊndɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒli smʌɡ.

Slowly, the sisters holding Egwene relaxed their grips, pulling her to her feet. She blinked against the blazing light of the lamps to find Katerine standing in the hallway a short distance away, her arms folded. "She is to be released," the Red said, sounding strangely smug.

"wʌt? " æskt wʌn ʌv ɛɡwinz kæptɝz. əz əɹ aɪz ədʒʌstəd, ɛɡwin kəd si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz læŋki bɑɹɑsin.

"What? " asked one of Egwene's captors. As her eyes adjusted, Egwene could see that it was lanky Barasine.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn əz ɹilaɪz ðət ʃiz pʌnɪʃɪŋ ðə ɹɔŋ pɝsən," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "ðə feɪljɝ laɪz nɑt kəmplitli ɑn ðə hɛɾ ə ðɪs . . . ɪnsɛkt ʌv ə nɑvəs, bʌɾ ɑn ðə wʌn u wɑz tə bi mənɪpjəleɪɾɪŋ hɝ."

"The Amyrlin has realized that she is punishing the wrong person," Katerine said. "The failure lies not completely on the head of this . . . insect of a novice, but on the one who was to be manipulating her."

ɛɡwin aɪd keɪɾɝin. ən ðən ɪt klɪkt ɪndə pleɪs. "sɪlviænə," ʃi sɛd.

Egwene eyed Katerine. And then it clicked into place. "Silviana," she said.

"ɪndid," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "ɪf ðə nɑvəsɪz ɑɹ aʊɾ ə kəntʃɹoʊl, ðən ʃəd nɑt ðə bleɪm fɔl ɑn ðə wʌn u wɑz tə tʃɹeɪn ðɛm?"

"Indeed," Katerine said. "If the novices are out of control, then should not the blame fall on the one who was to train them?"

soʊ ɪleɪɾə hæd ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi kəd nɑt pɹuv ɛɡwin wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. dɪflɛktɪŋ ətɛnʃən tə sɪlviænə wɑz ə klɛvɝ muv; ɪf ɪleɪɾə wɑz pʌnɪʃt fəɹ juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ tə biɾ ɛɡwin, bʌt sɪlviænə wɑz pʌnɪʃt fɑɹ mɔɹ fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ ɛɡwin ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə kəntʃɹoʊl, ɪt wəd seɪv feɪs fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn.

So Elaida had realized that she could not prove Egwene was a Darkfriend. Deflecting attention to Silviana was a clever move; if Elaida was punished for using the Power to beat Egwene, but Silviana was punished far more for letting Egwene get out of control, it would save face for the Amyrlin.

"aɪ θɪŋk ði æmɪɝlɪn meɪɾ ə waɪz tʃɔɪs," keɪɾɝin sɛd. "ɛɡwin, jə ɑɹ tə bi . . . ɪnstʃɹʌktəd fɹəm naʊ ɑn oʊnli baɪ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz."

"I think the Amyrlin made a wise choice," Katerine said. "Egwene, you are to be . . . instructed from now on only by the Mistress of Novices."

"bʌt sɪlviænə ɪz ðə wʌn jə sɛɾ əz feɪld," ɛɡwin sɛd, kənfjuzd.

"But Silviana is the one you said has failed," Egwene said, confused.

"nɑt sɪlviænə," keɪɾɝin sɛd; hɝ smʌɡnəs sim tə ɡɹoʊ ivən fɝðɝ. "ðə nu mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz."

"Not Silviana," Katerine said; her smugness seemed to grow even further. "The new Mistress of Novices."

ɛɡwin lɑkt ɡeɪzəz wɪð ðə wʊmən. "ɑ," ʃi sɛd. "æn jə bɪliv ðət jəl səksid wɛɹ sɪlviænə feɪld?"

Egwene locked gazes with the woman. "Ah," she said. "And you believe that you will succeed where Silviana failed?"

"ju wɪl si." keɪɾɝin tɝn əweɪ ən hɛɾəd daʊn ðə taɪl hɔlweɪ. "teɪk əɹ tə hɝ kɔɹɾɝz."

"You will see." Katerine turned away and headed down the tiled hallway. "Take her to her quarters."

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ɪleɪɾə wɑz mɔɹ kɑmpəɾənt ðən ɛɡwin hæɾ əsumd. ʃid sin ðət ði ɪmpɹɪzənmənt wɑznt wɝkɪŋ ən hæd faʊn ə skeɪpɡoʊt tə pʌnɪʃ ɪnstɛd. bʌt sɪlviænə, ɹimuv fɹəm əɹ pəzɪʃən əz mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz? ðət wəd bi ə bloʊ tə ðə mɝæl ə ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf, fəɹ mɛni sɪstɝz kənsɪɾɝd sɪlviænə ən ɪɡzɛmplɝi mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz.

Egwene shook her head. Elaida was more competent than Egwene had assumed. She'd seen that the imprisonment wasn't working and had found a scapegoat to punish instead. But Silviana, removed from her position as Mistress of Novices? That would be a blow to the morale of the Tower itself, for many sisters considered Silviana an exemplary Mistress of Novices.

ðə ɹɛdz ɹɪlʌktənli bɪɡæn tə wɔk ɛɡwin təwɔɹd ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz, naʊ ɪn ðɛɹ nu loʊkeɪʃən ɑn ðə twɛnti-sɛkən lɛvəl. ðeɪ simd ənɔɪd tə hæv mɪst aʊɾ ɑn ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə bit hɝ.

The Reds reluctantly began to walk Egwene toward the novices' quarters, now in their new location on the twenty-second level. They seemed annoyed to have missed out on the opportunity to beat her.

ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. æftɝ spɛndɪŋ soʊ lɔŋ lɑkt ʌp, ɪt fɛlt wʌndɝfəl sɪmpli tə bi eɪbəl tə wɔk. ɪt wɑzn fɹiɾəm, nɑt wɪð ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹdz, bʌɾ ɪt sɝɾənli dɪd fil laɪk ɪt! laɪt! ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən haʊ mɛni mɔɹ deɪz ɪn ðət dæŋk hoʊl ʌv ə sɛl ʃiɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə stænd!

She ignored them. After spending so long locked up, it felt wonderful simply to be able to walk. It wasn't freedom, not with a pair of guards, but it certainly did feel like it! Light! She wasn't certain how many more days in that dank hole of a cell she'd have been able to stand!

bʌt ʃid wʌn. ðə ɹiləzeɪʃən wɑz dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə dɔn ɑn hɝ. ʃid wʌn! ʃid ɹɪzɪstɪd ðə wɝs pʌnɪʃmən ɪleɪɾə kəd kəntʃɹaɪv, ən hæd kʌm aʊt vɪktɔɹiəs! ði æmɪɝlɪn wəd bi pʌnɪʃt baɪ ðə hɔl, ən ɛɡwin wəd ɡoʊ fɹi.

But she'd won. The realization was just beginning to dawn on her. She'd won! She'd resisted the worst punishment Elaida could contrive, and had come out victorious! The Amyrlin would be punished by the Hall, and Egwene would go free.

itʃ fəmɪljɝ hɔlweɪ sim tə ʃaɪn wɪð ə kənɡɹætʃələtɔɹi laɪt, ən itʃ stɛp ʃi tʊk sim laɪk ðə vɪktɝi mɑɹtʃ ʌv ə θaʊzən mɛn əkɹɔs ðə bæɾəlfild. ʃi hæd wʌn! ðə wɔɹ wɑz nɑɾ oʊvɝ, bʌt ðɪs bæɾəl wɛn tə ɛɡwin. ðeɪ klaɪm səm stɛɹz, ðən ɛntɝd ðə mɔɹ pɑpjəleɪɾəd sɛkʃənz ə ðə taʊɝ. sun, ʃi sɔ ə ɡɹup ə nɑvəsɪz pæsɪŋ; ðeɪ wɪspɝd tə wʌn ənʌðɝ əz ðeɪ sɔ ɛɡwin, ðən skæɾɝd əweɪ.

Each familiar hallway seemed to shine with a congratulatory light, and each step she took seemed like the victory march of a thousand men across the battlefield. She had won! The war was not over, but this battle went to Egwene. They climbed some stairs, then entered the more populated sections of the Tower. Soon, she saw a group of novices passing; they whispered to one another as they saw Egwene, then scattered away.

wɪðɪn mɪnəts, ɛɡwinz lɪɾəl pɹəsɛʃən ə θɹi bɪɡæn tə pæs mɔɹ ən mɔɹ pipəl ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz. sɪstɝz ʌv ɔl ədʒəz, lʊkɪŋ bɪzi - jɛt ðɛɹ stɛps sloʊɾ əz ðeɪ wɑtʃt ɛɡwin pæs.

Within minutes, Egwene's little procession of three began to pass more and more people in the hallways. Sisters of all Ajahs, looking busy - yet their steps slowed as they watched Egwene pass.

æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ bændɪd dʒɹɛsəz wɝ fɑɹ lɛs koʊvɝt; ðeɪ stʊɾ əɾ ɪntɝsɛkʃənz, ɡɔkɪŋ əz ɛɡwin wɑz lɛd pæst. ɪn ɔl ə ðɛɹ aɪz ðəɹ wɑz sɝpɹaɪz. waɪ wɑz ʃi fɹi? ðeɪ sim tɛns.

Accepted in their banded dresses were far less covert; they stood at intersections, gawking as Egwene was led past. In all of their eyes there was surprise. Why was she free? They seemed tense.

hæd sʌmθɪŋ hæpən ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑzn əwɛɹ ʌv?

Had something happened that Egwene wasn't aware of?

"ɑ, ɛɡwin," ə vɔɪs sɛɾ əz ðeɪ pæst ə hɔlweɪ. "ɛksələnt, jə ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi fɹi. aɪ wəd spik wɪð ju."

"Ah, Egwene," a voice said as they passed a hallway. "Excellent, you are already free. I would speak with you."

ɛɡwin tɝnd wɪð ʃɑk tə si sɹɪn, ðə pɝpəsfəl bɹaʊn sɪɾɝ. ðə skɑɹ ɑn ðə wʊmənz tʃik ɔlweɪz meɪɾ əɹ sim fɑɹ mɔɹ . . . dɔntɪŋ ðən moʊst ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ɛɹ ɛnhæns baɪ ðə waɪt lɑks ə hɛɹ, ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɹeɪɾ eɪdʒ. fju mɛmbɝz ə ðə bɹaʊn kəd bi dɪskɹaɪbd əz ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪŋ, bʌt sɹɪn wɑz sɝɾənli wʌn ə ðət səlɛkt ɡɹup.

Egwene turned with shock to see Saerin, the purposeful Brown Sitter. The scar on the woman's cheek always made her seem far more . . . daunting than most other Aes Sedai, an air enhanced by the white locks of hair, indicating her great age. Few members of the Brown could be described as intimidating, but Saerin was certainly one of that select group.

"wi ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ əɹ tə hɝ ɹumz," bɑɹɑsin sɛd.

"We are taking her to her rooms," Barasine said.

"wɛl, əl spik tə hɝ əz jə du," sɹɪn sɛd kɑmli.

"Well, I will speak to her as you do," Saerin said calmly.

"ʃi ɪz nɑt tə - "

"She is not to - "

"ju dɪnaɪ mi, ɹɛd? eɪ sɪɾɝ?" sɹɪn æskt.

"You deny me, Red? A Sitter?" Saerin asked.

bɑɹɑsin blʌʃt. "ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪl nɑt bi pliz tə hɪɹ ə ðɪs."

Barasine blushed. "The Amyrlin will not be pleased to hear of this."

"ðɛn ɹʌn əlɔŋ ən tɛl hɝ," sɹɪn sɛd. "waɪl aɪ dɪskʌs səm aɪɾəmz ʌv ɪmpɔɹt wɪð jʌŋ ælvɪɹ." ʃi aɪd ðə ɹɛdz. "ɡɪv əs səm ɹum, ɪf jə pliz."

"Then run along and tell her," Saerin said. "While I discuss some items of import with young al'Vere." She eyed the Reds. "Give us some room, if you please."

ðə tu ɹɛdz feɪl tə stɛɹ əɹ daʊn, ðən bækt əweɪ. ɛɡwin wɑtʃt wɪð kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət ði əθɔɹəɾi ʌv ði æmɪɝlɪn - ɪndid, ðəɾ ə hɝ ɪntaɪɝ ədʒɑ - wɑz sʌmwʌt dɪmd.

The two Reds failed to stare her down, then backed away. Egwene watched with curiosity. It appeared that the authority of the Amyrlin - indeed, that of her entire Ajah - was somewhat dimmed.

sɹɪn tɝn tə ɛɡwin ən dʒɛstʃɝd, ən ðə tu ʌv əm bɪɡæn tə wɔk təɡɛðɝ θɹu ðə hɔlweɪ, ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz fɑloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪnd.

Saerin turned to Egwene and gestured, and the two of them began to walk together through the hallway, the Red sisters following behind.

"ju teɪk ə ɹɪsk biɪŋ sin spikɪŋ tə mi laɪk ðɪs," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"You take a risk being seen speaking to me like this," Egwene said.

sɹɪn snɪft. "livɪŋ wʌnz kɔɹɾɝz ɪz teɪkɪŋ ə ɹɪsk, ðiz deɪz. aɪm ɡɹoʊɪŋ tu fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd wɪð ɪvɛns tə bɑðɝ wɪð naɪsɪɾiz ɛnimɔɹ." ʃi pɔzd, ðən ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin. "bɪsaɪdz. biɪŋ sin ɪn jəɹ kʌmpəni kən bi ɹæðɝ wɝθ ðət ɹɪsk, ðiz deɪz. aɪ wɑntəd tə dətɝmən sʌmθɪŋ."

Saerin sniffed. "Leaving one's quarters is taking a risk, these days. I'm growing too frustrated with events to bother with niceties anymore." She paused, then glanced at Egwene. "Besides. Being seen in your company can be rather worth that risk, these days. I wanted to determine something."

"wʌt?" ɛɡwin æskt, kjʊɹiəs.

"What?" Egwene asked, curious.

"wɛl, aɪ æktʃəli  wɑntəd tə si ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi pʊʃt ɝaʊnd. moʊst ə ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə ɹɛɾ ɑɹ nɑt teɪkɪŋ jəɹ ɹilis wɛl. ðeɪ si ɪɾ əz ə meɪdʒɝ feɪlɪŋ ɑn ɪleɪɾəz pɑɹt."

"Well, I actually wanted to see if they could be pushed around. Most of the members of the Red are not taking your release well. They see it as a major failing on Elaida's part."

"ʃi ʃʊɾə kɪl mi," ɛɡwin sɛd wɪð ə nɑd. "deɪz əɡoʊ."

"She should have killed me," Egwene said with a nod. "Days ago."

"ðæt wʊɾə bɪn sin əz ə feɪljɝ."

"That would have been seen as a failure."

"æz mʌtʃ ə feɪljɝ əz biɪŋ fɔɹs tə ɹimuv sɪlviænə?" ɛɡwin æskt. "ʌv sʌɾənli dəsaɪɾɪŋ ðət jəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ɪz tə bleɪm, ə wik æftɝ ðə fækt?"

"As much a failure as being forced to remove Silviana?" Egwene asked. "Of suddenly deciding that your Mistress of Novices is to blame, a week after the fact?"

"ɪz ðət wʌt ðeɪ toʊl ju?" sɹɪn æskt, smaɪlɪŋ əz ðeɪ wɔkt, hɝ aɪz fɔɹwɝd. "ðæɾ ɪleɪɾə 'sʌɾənli' keɪm tə ðɪs dɪsɪʒən, ɔl ɑn əɹ oʊn?"

"Is that what they told you?" Saerin asked, smiling as they walked, her eyes forward. "That Elaida 'suddenly' came to this decision, all on her own?"

ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

Egwene raised an eyebrow.

"sɪlviænə dɪmændəd tə bi hɝd baɪ ðə fʊl hɔl waɪl ɪt wɑz sɪɾɪŋ," sɹɪn ɪkspleɪnd. "ʃi stʊd bɪfɔɹ ðə lɑɾ ʌv ʌs, bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪɾə hɝsɛlf, ən ɪnsɪstəd ðət jəɹ tʃɹitmənt wɑz ənlɔfəl.

"Silviana demanded to be heard by the full Hall while it was sitting," Saerin explained. "She stood before the lot of us, before Elaida herself, and insisted that your treatment was unlawful.

wɪtʃ, laɪkli, ɪt wɑz. ivən ɪf jə ɑɹən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, jə ʃʊdn əv bɪn pleɪst ɪn sətʃ tɛɹəbəl kəndɪʃənz." sɹɪn ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin. "sɪlviænə dɪmændəd jəɹ ɹilis. ʃi sim tə ɹɪspɛk jə ə ɡɹeɪt dil, aɪ ʃəd seɪ. ʃi spoʊk wɪð pɹaɪɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs ə haʊ jud ɹəsiv jəɹ pʌnɪʃməns, əz ɪf jə wɝ ə stuɾənt u hæd lɝn əɹ lɛsən wɛl. ʃi dɪnaʊnst ɪleɪɾə, kɔlɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə bi ɹimuvd əz æmɪɝlɪn. ɪt wɑz . . . kwaɪɾ ɪkstʃɹɔɹɾənɛɹi."

Which, likely, it was. Even if you aren't an Aes Sedai, you shouldn't have been placed in such terrible conditions." Saerin glanced at Egwene. "Silviana demanded your release. She seemed to respect you a great deal, I should say. She spoke with pride in her voice of how you'd received your punishments, as if you were a student who had learned her lesson well. She denounced Elaida, calling for her to be removed as Amyrlin. It was . . . quite extraordinary."

"baɪ ðə laɪt . . ." ɛɡwin bɹiðd. "wʌt dɪɾ ɪleɪɾə də tə hɝ?"

"By the Light . . ." Egwene breathed. "What did Elaida do to her?"

"ɔɹɾɝd əɹ tə teɪk ʌp ðə dʒɹɛs ʌv ə nɑvəs," sɹɪn sɛd. "dʒʌst əbaʊt kɑzd ən ʌpɹɔɹ ɪn ðə hɔl ɪtsɛlf." sɹɪn pɔzd. "sɪlviænə ɹəfjuzd, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪleɪɾə hæz dɪklɛɹd ðət ʃiz tə bi stɪld ən ɛksəkjuɾəd. ðə hɔl dʌznt noʊ wʌt tə du."

"Ordered her to take up the dress of a novice," Saerin said. "Just about caused an uproar in the Hall itself." Saerin paused. "Silviana refused, of course. Elaida has declared that she is to be stilled and executed. The Hall doesn't know what to do."

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə stæb ə pænɪk. "laɪt! ʃi mʌsnt bi pʌnɪʃt! wi mʌs pɹɪvɛn ðɪs."

Egwene felt a stab of panic. "Light! She mustn't be punished! We must prevent this."

"pɹɪvɛn ɪt?" sɹɪn æskt. "tʃaɪld, ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɪz kɹʌmbəlɪŋ! ɪts mɛmbɝz ɑɹ tɝnɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ, wʊlvz ətækɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn pæk. ɪf ɪleɪɾə ɪz əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ θɹu wɪð kɪlɪŋ wʌn ə hɝ oʊn ədʒɑ, wʌtɛvɝ səpɔɹt ʃi hæd fɹəm wɪðɪn ðə ɹæŋks wɪl ɪvæpɝeɪt. waɪ, aɪ wʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪzd, wən ðə dʌst sɛɾəlz, tə si ðət ði ədʒɑ hæz ʌndɝmaɪn ɪtsɛlf tə ðə pɔɪn ðət jə kəd sɪmpli dɪsbæn ɪɾ ən bi dʌn wɪð ðɛm."

"Prevent it?" Saerin asked. "Child, the Red Ajah is crumbling! Its members are turning against one another, wolves attacking their own pack. If Elaida is allowed to go through with killing one of her own Ajah, whatever support she had from within the ranks will evaporate. Why, I wouldn't be surprised, when the dust settles, to see that the Ajah has undermined itself to the point that you could simply disband it and be done with them."

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə dɪsbæn ðɛm," ɛɡwin sɛd. "sɹɪn, ðæts wʌn ə ðə pɹɑbləmz wɪð ɪleɪɾəz weɪ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs! ðə waɪt taʊɝ nidz ɔl ə ði ədʒəz, ivən ðə ɹɛd, tə feɪs wʌɾ ɪz kʌmɪŋ. wi sɝɾənli kæn əfɔɹd tə luz ə wʊmən laɪk sɪlviænə dʒʌs tə meɪk ə pɔɪnt. ɹæli wʌt səpɔɹt jə kæn. wɪv tə muv kwɪkli tə stɑp ðɪs tʃɹævəsti."

"I don't want to disband them," Egwene said. "Saerin, that's one of the problems with Elaida's way of thinking in the first place! The White Tower needs all of the Ajahs, even the Red, to face what is coming. We certainly can't afford to lose a woman like Silviana just to make a point. Rally what support you can. We have to move quickly to stop this travesty."

sɹɪn blɪŋkt. "du jə ɹɪli θɪŋk jəɹ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl hɪɹ, tʃaɪld?"

Saerin blinked. "Do you really think you're in control here, child?"

ɛɡwin mɛɾ əɹ aɪz. "du jə wɑnə bi?"

Egwene met her eyes. "Do you want to be?"

"laɪt, noʊ!"

"Light, no!"

"wɛl, ðən stɑp stændɪŋ ɪn maɪ weɪ ən ɡɛt tə wɝk! ɪleɪɾə mʌs bi ɹimuvd, bʌt wi kæn lɛt ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ kəlæps ɝaʊn əs waɪl ɪt hæpənz. ɡoʊ tə ðə hɔl ən si wʌt jə kən də tə stɑp ðɪs!"

"Well, then stop standing in my way and get to work! Elaida must be removed, but we can't let the entire Tower collapse around us while it happens. Go to the Hall and see what you can do to stop this!"

sɹɪn æktʃəli  nɑɾəd ɪn ɹɪspɛk bɪfɔɹ wɪθdʒɹɔɪŋ daʊn ə saɪd kɔɹəɾɝ. ɛɡwin ɡlæns bæk əɾ əɹ tu ɹɛɾ ətɛndəns. "dɪd jə hɪɹ mʌtʃ ə ðæt?"

Saerin actually nodded in respect before withdrawing down a side corridor. Egwene glanced back at her two Red attendants. "Did you hear much of that?"

ðeɪ ɡlænst əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ. ʌv kɔɹs ðeɪd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ. "jul wɑnə ɡoʊ dətɝmən fəɹ jʊɹsɛlvz wʌɾ əz hæpənd," ɛɡwin sɛd. "waɪ hævən ju?"

They glanced at each other. Of course they'd been listening. "You'll want to go determine for yourselves what has happened," Egwene said. "Why haven't you?"

ðə tu ɡlænst əɾ əɹ wɪð ənɔɪəns. "ðə ʃild," bɑɹɑsin sɛd. "wiv bɪn ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə ɔlweɪz əv ət lis tu tə meɪnteɪn ɪt."

The two glanced at her with annoyance. "The shield," Barasine said. "We've been instructed to always have at least two to maintain it."

"oʊ, fəɹ ðə. . . ." ɛɡwin tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ɪf aɪ vaʊ nɑt tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə paʊɝ əntɪl aɪm pɹɑpɝli bæk ɪn ðə kʌstəɾi ʌv ənʌðɝ ɹɛd sɪstɝ, wɪl ðət bi ɪnʌf fəɹ ju?"

"Oh, for the. . . ." Egwene took a deep breath. "If I vow not to embrace the Power until I am properly back in the custody of another Red sister, will that be enough for you?"

ðə tu ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ wɪð səspɪʃən.

The two regarded her with suspicion.

"aɪ səspɛktəɾ əz mʌtʃ," ɛɡwin sɛd. ʃi tɝn tə ə ɡɹup ə nɑvəsɪz u wɝ stændɪŋ ɪn ə saɪd kɔɹəɾɝ, pɹitɛndɪŋ tə skɹʌb ðə taɪlz ɑn ðə saɪd wɔl waɪl ðeɪ ɡɔkt əɾ ɛɡwin.

"I suspected as much," Egwene said. She turned to a group of novices who were standing in a side corridor, pretending to scrub the tiles on the side wall while they gawked at Egwene.

"ju," ɛɡwin sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ tə wʌn ə ðɛm. "mɑɹzəl, ɪzən ɪt?"

"You," Egwene said, pointing to one of them. "Marsial, isn't it?"

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," ðə ɡɝl skwikt.

"Yes, Mother," the girl squeaked.

"ɡoʊ ən fɛtʃ əs səm fɔkɹut ti. keɪɾɝin ʃəɾ əv səm ət ðə stʌɾi ʌv ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. ɪts nɑt fɑɹ. tɛl əɹ ðət bɑɹɑsin ɹɪkwɛstɪɾ ɪt fəɹ jus ɑn mi; bɹɪŋ ɪt tə maɪ kɔɹɾɝz."

"Go and fetch us some forkroot tea. Katerine should have some at the study of the Mistress of Novices. It's not far. Tell her that Barasine requested it for use on me; bring it to my quarters."

ðə nɑvəs skɹæmbəld ɔf tə də əz æskt.

The novice scrambled off to do as asked.

"aɪl doʊs maɪsɛlf wɪð ðæt, ən ðən ət list wʌn ə jə kən ɡoʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "jɔɹ ədʒɑ ɪz kəlæpsɪŋ. ðəɹ gɑnə niɾ ɔl ə ðə klɪɹ maɪnz ðeɪ kən ɡɛt; meɪbi jə kən kənvɪns jəɹ sɪstɝz ðəɾ ɪts ənwaɪz tə lɛɾ ɪleɪɾə ɛksəkjut sɪlviænə."

"I'll dose myself with that, and then at least one of you can go," Egwene said. "Your Ajah is collapsing. They're going to need all of the clear minds they can get; maybe you can convince your sisters that it is unwise to let Elaida execute Silviana."

ðə tu ɹɛdz ɡlænst əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ənsɝteɪnli. ðən ðə spɪnli wʌn huz neɪm ɛɡwin dɪdnt noʊ kɝst sɔfli ən hɝiɾ əweɪ wɪð ə flɝi ʌv ɹʌslɪŋ skɝts. bɑɹɑsin kɔld æftɝ hɝ, bʌt ðə wʊmən dɪdn ɹɪtɝn.

The two Reds glanced at each other uncertainly. Then the spindly one whose name Egwene didn't know cursed softly and hurried away with a flurry of rustling skirts. Barasine called after her, but the woman didn't return.

bɑɹɑsin ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin, mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, bʌt ɹɪmeɪn ɪn pleɪs. "wɝ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðət fɔkɹut," ʃi sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ɛɡwin ɪn ði aɪz. "kip muvɪŋ ɑn tə jəɹ kɔɹɾɝz."

Barasine glanced at Egwene, muttered something under her breath, but remained in place. "We're waiting for that forkroot," she said, staring Egwene in the eyes. "Keep moving on to your quarters."

"faɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌɾ itʃ mɪnət jə dɪleɪ kəd kɑs jə dipli."

"Fine," Egwene said. "But each minute you delay could cost you deeply."

ðeɪ klaɪm ðə stɛɹz tə ðə nu nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz, wɪtʃ wɝ skɹʌntʃt ʌp əlɔŋsaɪd ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ ə ðə bɹaʊn sɛkʃən ə ðə taʊɝ. ðeɪ stɑp baɪ ɛɡwinz dɔɹ tə weɪt fəɹ ðə fɔkɹut. əz ðeɪ stʊd ðɛɹ, nɑvəsɪz bɪɡæn tə kɹaʊɾ ɝaʊnd. ɪn ðə dɪstən kɔɹɪɾɝz, sɪstɝz ən ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz ɹæn θɹu hɔlweɪz wɪð ə sɛns ə ɝdʒənsi. hoʊpfəli, ðə hɔl wəd bi eɪbəl tə də sʌmθɪŋ tə kənteɪn ɪleɪɾə. ɪf ʃi ɹɪli wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə ɛksəkjut sɪstɝz fəɹ sɪmpli dɪsəɡɹiɪŋ wɪð hɝ. . . .

They climbed the stairs to the new novices' quarters, which were scrunched up alongside the remainder of the Brown section of the Tower. They stopped by Egwene's door to wait for the forkroot. As they stood there, novices began to crowd around. In the distant corridors, sisters and their Warders ran through hallways with a sense of urgency. Hopefully, the Hall would be able to do something to contain Elaida. If she really went so far as to execute sisters for simply disagreeing with her. . . .

ðə waɪd-aɪd nɑvəs faɪnəli ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ə kʌp ən ə smɔl pækəɾ ə ɝbz. bɑɹɑsin ɪnspɛktɪd ðə pækəɾ ən əpɛɹənli dɪtɝmən ðəɾ ɪt wɑz sæɾəsfæktʃɹi, fəɹ ʃi dʌmpt ɪɾ ɪndə ðə kʌp ən pɹɑfɝɾ ɪt tə ɛɡwin ɪkspɛktənli. wɪð ə saɪ, ɛɡwin tʊk ɪɾ ən daʊn ði ɪntaɪɝ kʌp ʌv wɔɹm wɔɾɝ. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf ʌv ə doʊs ðət ʃi wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ə tʃɹɪkəl, bʌt hoʊpfəli wʊdn bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹɛndɝ əɹ ʌnkɑnʃəs.

The wide-eyed novice finally returned with a cup and a small packet of herbs. Barasine inspected the packet and apparently determined that it was satisfactory, for she dumped it into the cup and proffered it to Egwene expectantly. With a sigh, Egwene took it and downed the entire cup of warm water. It was enough of a dose that she wouldn't be able to channel a trickle, but hopefully wouldn't be strong enough to render her unconscious.

bɑɹɑsin tɝn ən hɝiɾ əweɪ, livɪŋ ɛɡwin əloʊn ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. nɑt dʒʌst əloʊn, bʌɾ əloʊn ən eɪbəl tə də ɪɡzækli əz ʃi wɪʃt. ʃi dɪdnt ɡɛt mɛni ʌv ðiz ɑpɝtunəɾiz.

Barasine turned and hurried away, leaving Egwene alone in the hallway. Not just alone, but alone and able to do exactly as she wished. She didn't get many of these opportunities.

wɛl, ʃiɾ əv tə si wʌt ʃi kəd də wɪð ðæt. bʌt fɝst, ʃid nid tə tʃeɪnʒ aʊɾ ə ðɪs fɪlθi, blʌdsteɪn dʒɹɛs, ən wɑʃ hɝsɛlf, tu. ʃi pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə hɝ kɔɹɾɝz.

Well, she'd have to see what she could do with that. But first, she'd need to change out of this filthy, bloodstained dress, and wash herself, too. She pushed open the door to her quarters.

ən faʊn sʌmwʌn sɪɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd.

And found someone sitting inside.

A Visit from Verin Sedai "You never held the Oath Rod," Egwene accused her, still standing by the closet. Verin remained on the side of the bed, sipping her tea. The stout woman wore a simple brown dress with a matronly cut through the bosom and a thick leather belt at the waist. "vɛɹɪn, aɪ. . . ." ɛɡwin pɔzd. "wʌɾ ɪz - "

"Verin, I. . . ." Egwene paused. "What is - "

"noʊ taɪm, aɪm əfɹeɪd," vɛɹɪn sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. sʌɾənli, sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ sim tə tʃeɪnʒ. ðoʊ ʃi wɑz stɪl ði eɪdʒɪd - ən ət taɪmz mʌðɝli - wʊmən, hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu mɔɹ dɪtɝmənd. ʃi kɑɾ ɛɡwinz aɪz, ən ði ɪntɛnsəɾi wɪðɪn ðət ɡeɪz ʃɑkt ɛɡwin. wɑz ðɪs ðə seɪm wʊmən?

"No time, I'm afraid," Verin said, leaning forward. Suddenly, something about her seemed to change. Though she was still the aged - and at times motherly - woman, her expression grew more determined. She caught Egwene's eyes, and the intensity within that gaze shocked Egwene. Was this the same woman?

"θæŋk jə fəɹ hjumɝɪŋ ə wʊmənz ɹæmbəlz," vɛɹɪn sɛd, vɔɪs mɔɹ sɑft. "ɪt wɑz soʊ vɛɹi naɪs tə hæv ə kwaɪət tʃæɾ oʊvɝ ti, ət list wʌns mɔɹ. naʊ, ðəɹ ɑɹ səm θɪŋz jə nid tə noʊ. ə nʌmbɝ ə jɪɹz əɡoʊ, aɪ feɪst ə dɪsɪʒən. aɪ faʊn maɪsɛlf ɪn ə pəzɪʃən wɛɹ aɪ kəɾ iðɝ teɪk ði oʊðz tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, əɹ aɪ kəd ɹɪvil ðəɾ aɪ hæɾ æktʃəli  nɛvɝ wɑntəd - əɹ ɪntɛndəd - tə də soʊ, wɛɹəpɑn wʊɾə əv bɪn ɛksəkjuɾəd.

"Thank you for humoring a woman's rambles," Verin said, voice more soft. "It was so very nice to have a quiet chat over tea, at least once more. Now, there are some things you need to know. A number of years ago, I faced a decision. I found myself in a position where I could either take the oaths to the Dark One, or I could reveal that I had actually never wanted - or intended - to do so, whereupon I would have been executed.

"pɝhæps ənʌðɝ wʊɾə faʊn ə weɪ ɝaʊn ðɪs sɪtʃueɪʃən. mɛni wəɾ əv sɪmpli ɑptɪd fəɹ dɛθ. aɪ, haʊɛvɝ, sɔ ðɪs əz ən ɑpɝtunəɾi. jə si, wʌn ɹɛɹli hæz sətʃ ə tʃæns əz ðɪs, tə stʌɾi ə bis fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ ɪts hɑɹt, tə si ɹɪli wʌt meɪks ðə blʌd floʊ. tə dɪskʌvɝ wɛɹ ɔl ə ðə lɪɾəl veɪnz ən vɛsəlz lɛd. kwaɪɾ ən ɪkstʃɹɔɹɾənɛɹi ɪkspɪɹiəns."

"Perhaps another would have found a way around this situation. Many would have simply opted for death. I, however, saw this as an opportunity. You see, one rarely has such a chance as this, to study a beast from inside its heart, to see really what makes the blood flow. To discover where all of the little veins and vessels lead. Quite an extraordinary experience."

"weɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ju dʒɔɪn ðə blæk ədʒɑ tə stʌɾi ðɛm?"

"Wait," Egwene said. "You joined the Black Ajah to study them?"

"aɪ dʒɔɪn əm tə kip maɪ skɪn ɪntækt," vɛɹɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "aɪm ɹæðɝ fɑn ʌv ɪt, ðoʊ toʊmɑs dɪd ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊt ðiz waɪt hɛɹz. ɛniweɪ, æftɝ dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðɛm, ðə tʃæns tə stʌɾi ðɛm wɑz maɪ meɪkɪŋ ðə bɛst ə ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən."

"I joined them to keep my skin intact," Verin said, smiling. "I'm rather fond of it, though Tomas did go on about these white hairs. Anyway, after joining them, the chance to study them was my making the best of the situation."

"toʊmɑs. dʌz i noʊ wʌt juv dʌn?"

"Tomas. Does he know what you've done?"

"hi wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛn hɪmsɛlf, tʃaɪld," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "wɑntɪŋ ə weɪ aʊt. wɛl, ðəɹ ɹɪli ɪzən ə weɪ aʊt, nɑt wʌns ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ əz ɪz klɔz ɪn ju. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ tə faɪt, tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ə lɪɾəl ʌv wʌt juv dʌn. aɪ ɔfɝd ðət tʃæns tə toʊmɑs, ən aɪ bɪliv i wɑz kwaɪt ɡɹeɪtfəl tə mi fəɹ ɪt."

"He was a Darkfriend himself, child," Verin said. "Wanting a way out. Well, there really isn't a way out, not once the Great Lord has his claws in you. But there was a way to fight, to make up for a little of what you've done. I offered that chance to Tomas, and I believe he was quite grateful to me for it."

ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk ɔl ə ðɪs ɪn. vɛɹɪn wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd . . . bʌt nɑt wʌn ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "ju sɛɾ i 'wɑz' kwaɪt ɡɹeɪtfəl tə ju?"

Egwene hesitated, trying to take all of this in. Verin was a Darkfriend . . . but not one at the same time. "You said he 'was' quite grateful to you?"

vɛɹɪn dɪdn ænsɝ ɪmiɾiətli. ʃi sɪmpli tʊk ənʌðɝ sɪp ə hɝ ti. "ði oʊðz wʌn meɪks tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ɑɹ kwaɪt spəsɪfɪk," ʃi faɪnəli kəntɪnjud. "ænd, wən ðeɪ ɑɹ pleɪst əpɑn wʌn u kən tʃænəl, ðeɪ ɑɹ kwaɪt baɪndɪŋ. ɪmpɑsəbəl tə bɹeɪk. jə kən dʌbəl-kɹɔs ʌðɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, jə kən tɝn əɡɛns ðə tʃoʊzən ɪf jə kən dʒʌstəfaɪ ɪt. sɛlfɪʃnəs mʌs bi pɹəzɝvd. bʌt jə kən nɛvɝ bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪm. jə kən nɛvɝ bɪtʃɹeɪ ði ɔɹɾɝ ɪtsɛlf tə aʊtsaɪɾɝz. bʌt ði oʊðz ɑɹ spəsɪfɪk. vɛɹi spəsɪfɪk." ʃi lʊkt ʌp, miɾɪŋ ɛɡwinz aɪz. " 'aɪ swɛɹ nɑt tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, tə kip maɪ sikɹəts əntɪl ði aʊɝ ə maɪ dɛθ.' ðət wɑz wʌɾ aɪ pɹɑməst. dʒju si?"

Verin didn't answer immediately. She simply took another sip of her tea. "The oaths one makes to the Great Lord are quite specific," she finally continued. "And, when they are placed upon one who can channel, they are quite binding. Impossible to break. You can double-cross other Darkfriends, you can turn against the Chosen if you can justify it. Selfishness must be preserved. But you can never betray him. You can never betray the order itself to outsiders. But the oaths are specific. Very specific." She looked up, meeting Egwene's eyes. " 'I swear not to betray the Great Lord, to keep my secrets until the hour of my death.' That was what I promised. Do you see?"

ɛɡwin lʊk daʊn ət ðə stimɪŋ kʌp ɪn vɛɹɪnz hænz. "pɔɪzən?"

Egwene looked down at the steaming cup in Verin's hands. "Poison?"

"ɪt teɪks ə vɛɹi spɛʃəl ti tə meɪk æspɪŋ ɹɑt ɡoʊ daʊn switli," vɛɹɪn sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ sɪp.

"It takes a very special tea to make asping rot go down sweetly," Verin said, taking another sip.

"æz aɪ sɛd, pliz θæŋk lɑɹəz fəɹ mi."

"As I said, please thank Laras for me."

ɛɡwin kloʊzd əɹ aɪz. nɪneɪiv hæd mɛnʃən æspɪŋ ɹɑt tə hɝ; ə dʒɹɑp kəd kɪl. ɪt wɑz ə kwɪk dɛθ, pisfəl, ən ɔfən keɪm . . . wɪðɪn ən aʊɝ ʌv ɪndʒɛstʃən.

Egwene closed her eyes. Nynaeve had mentioned asping rot to her; a drop could kill. It was a quick death, peaceful, and often came . . . within an hour of ingestion.

"ə kjʊɹiəs hoʊl ɪn ði oʊðz," vɛɹɪn sɛd sɔfli. "tə əlaʊ wʌn tə ɪfɛkt ə bɪtʃɹeɪəl ɪn ðə faɪnəl aʊɝ ʌv wʌnz laɪf. aɪ kænɑt hɛlp wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd noʊz ʌv ɪt. waɪ wʊdn i kloʊs ðət hoʊl?"

"A curious hole in the oaths," Verin said softly. "To allow one to effect a betrayal in the final hour of one's life. I cannot help wondering if the Great Lord knows of it. Why wouldn't he close that hole?"

"pɝhæps i dʌzn si ɪɾ əz θɹɛɾənɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd, oʊpənɪŋ əɹ aɪz. "æftɝ ɔl, wʌt kaɪndə dɑɹkfɹɛnd wəd kɪl ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ədvæns ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɡʊd? ɪt dʌzn sim ðə kaɪndə θɪŋ ɪz fɑloʊɝz wəd kənsɪɾɝ."

"Perhaps he doesn't see it as threatening," Egwene said, opening her eyes. "After all, what kind of Darkfriend would kill themselves in order to advance the greater good? It doesn't seem the kind of thing his followers would consider."

"ju meɪ bi ɹaɪɾ ət ðæt," vɛɹɪn sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ ðə kʌp ə ti əsaɪd. "ɪt wəd bi waɪz tə meɪk sɝɾən ðəɾ ɪz dɪspoʊzd ʌv wɪð kɛɹ, tʃaɪld."

"You may be right at that," Verin said, setting the cup of tea aside. "It would be wise to make certain that is disposed of with care, child."

"soʊ ðəɾ ɪz ɪt?" ɛɡwin æskt, tʃɪld. "wʌɾ ə toʊmɑs?"

"So that is it?" Egwene asked, chilled. "What of Tomas?"

"wi meɪɾ əɹ fɛɹwɛlz. hiz spɛndɪŋ ɪz læst aʊɝ wɪð fæmli."

"We made our farewells. He is spending his last hour with family."

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ɪt sim sətʃ ə tʃɹædʒəɾi. "ju kʌm tə mi tə kənfɛs, kɪlɪŋ jɝsɛlf ɪn ə faɪnəl kwɛs fəɹ ɹɪdɛmpʃən?"

Egwene shook her head. It seemed such a tragedy. "You come to me to confess, killing yourself in a final quest for redemption?"

vɛɹɪn læft. "ɹɪdɛmpʃən? aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk ðət wʊdn bi soʊ izəli ɝnd. laɪt noʊz aɪv dʌn ɪnʌf tə ɹikwaɪɝ ə vɛɹi spɛʃəl kaɪndə ɹɪdɛmpʃən. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz wɝθ ðə kɑst. wɝθ ɪɾ ɪndid.

Verin laughed. "Redemption? I should think that wouldn't be so easily earned. Light knows I've done enough to require a very special kind of redemption. But it was worth the cost. Worth it indeed.

əɹ pɝhæps ðəɾ ɪz sɪmpli wʌɾ aɪ mʌs tɛl maɪsɛlf." ʃi ɹitʃt tə hɝ saɪd, pʊlɪŋ ə lɛðɝ skɹɪp fɹəm bɪniθ ðə foʊldəd blæŋkəɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ʌv ɛɡwinz bɛd. vɛɹɪn kɛɹfəli əndɪd ðə stʃɹæps, ðən pɹədus tu aɪɾəmz: tu bʊks, boʊθ baʊn ɪn lɛðɝ. wʌn wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ, laɪk ə ɹɛfɝəns bʊk, ðoʊ ɪt hæd noʊ taɪɾəl ɑn ɪts ɹɛd baɪndɪŋ. ði ʌðɝ wɑz ə θɪn blu bʊk. ðə kʌvɝz ə boʊθ wɝ ə lɪɾəl wɔɹn fɹəm jus.

Or perhaps that is simply what I must tell myself." She reached to her side, pulling a leather scrip from beneath the folded blanket at the foot of Egwene's bed. Verin carefully undid the straps, then produced two items: two books, both bound in leather. One was larger, like a reference book, though it had no title on its red binding. The other was a thin blue book. The covers of both were a little worn from use.

vɛɹɪn hændəɾ əm tə ɛɡwin. hɛzɪɾəntli ʃi tʊk ðɛm, ðə lɑɹdʒɝ vɑljum hɛvi ɪn əɹ ɹaɪt hænd, ðə blu bʊk laɪɾ ɪn əɹ lɛf hænd. ʃi ɹæn ə fɪŋɡɝ oʊvɝ ðə smuð lɛðɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət vɛɹɪn.

Verin handed them to Egwene. Hesitantly she took them, the larger volume heavy in her right hand, the blue book light in her left hand. She ran a finger over the smooth leather, frowning. She looked up at Verin.

"ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə bɹaʊn," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "siks tə pɹədus sʌmθɪŋ læstɪŋ. ɹisɝtʃ əɹ stʌɾi ðət wɪl bi minɪŋfəl. ʌðɝz ɔfən əkjuz əs ʌv ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə wɝld ɝaʊn ʌs. ðeɪ θɪŋk wi oʊnli lʊk bækwɝd. wɛl, ðəɾ ɪz ɪnækjɝət. ɪf wəɹ dɪstʃɹæktəd, ɪts kəz wi lʊk fɔɹwɝd, təwɔɹd ðoʊz u wɪl kʌm. ən ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, ðə nɑlədʒ wi ɡæðɝ . . . wi liv ɪt fəɹ ðɛm. ði ʌðɝ ədʒəz wɝi əbaʊt meɪkɪŋ tədeɪ bɛɾɝ; wi jɝn tə meɪk təmɑɹoʊ bɛɾɝ."

"Every woman in the Brown," Verin said, "seeks to produce something lasting. Research or study that will be meaningful. Others often accuse us of ignoring the world around us. They think we only look backward. Well, that is inaccurate. If we are distracted, it is because we look forward, toward those who will come. And the information, the knowledge we gather . . . we leave it for them. The other Ajahs worry about making today better; we yearn to make tomorrow better."

ɛɡwin sɛt ðə blu bʊk əsaɪd, lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹɛd wʌn fɝst. ðə wɝdz wɝ ɹɪɾən ɪn ə smɔl, ɪfɪʃənt, bʌt kɹæmp hænd ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əz vɛɹɪnz. nʌn ə ðə sɛntənsəz meɪd sɛns. ðeɪ wɝ ɡɪbɝɪʃ.

Egwene set the blue book aside, looking into the red one first. The words were written in a small, efficient, but cramped hand she recognized as Verin's. None of the sentences made sense. They were gibberish.

"ðə smɔl bʊk ɪz ə ki, ɛɡwin," vɛɹɪn ɪkspleɪnd. "ɪt kənteɪnz ðə saɪfɝ aɪ juz tə ɹaɪt ðɪs toʊm. ðət toʊm ɪz ðə . . . wɝk. maɪ wɝk. ðə wɝk ə maɪ laɪf."

"The small book is a key, Egwene," Verin explained. "It contains the cipher I used to write this tome. That tome is the . . . work. My work. The work of my life."

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" ɛɡwin æsk sɔfli, səspɛktɪŋ ʃi maɪt noʊ ði ænsɝ.

"What is it?" Egwene asked softly, suspecting she might know the answer.

"neɪmz, loʊkeɪʃənz, ɛkspləneɪʃənz," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ lɝn əbaʊt ðɛm. əbaʊt ðə liɾɝz əmʌŋ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ðə pɹɑfəsiz ðeɪ bɪliv, ðə ɡoʊlz ən moʊɾəveɪʃənz ə ðə sɛpɹət fækʃənz. əlɔŋ wɪð ə lɪst, ət ðə bæk, ʌv ɛvɹi blæk ədʒɑ sɪstɝ aɪ kəɾ aɪdɛntəfaɪ."

"Names, locations, explanations," Verin said. "Everything I learned about them. About the leaders among the Darkfriends, about the Black Ajah. The prophecies they believe, the goals and motivations of the separate factions. Along with a list, at the back, of every Black Ajah sister I could identify."

ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd. "ɛvɹi wʌn?"

Egwene started. "Every one?"

"aɪ daʊɾ aɪ kɑɾ əm ɔl," vɛɹɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk aɪ ɡɑt ðə lɑɹdʒ mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ðɛm. aɪ pɹɑməs ju, ɛɡwin. aɪ kən bi kwaɪt θɝoʊ."

"I doubt I caught them all," Verin said, smiling. "But I think I got the large majority of them. I promise you, Egwene. I can be quite thorough."

ɛɡwin lʊk daʊn ət ðə bʊks wɪð ɑ. ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl! laɪt, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə tʃɹɛʒɝ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɛni kɪŋz hɔɹd. ə tʃɹɛʒɝ əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪtsɛlf. ʃi lʊkt ʌp, tɪɹz ɪn əɹ aɪz, ɪmædʒənɪŋ ə laɪf spɛn əmʌŋ ðə blæk, ɔlweɪz wɑtʃɪŋ, ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ, ən wɝkɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv ɔl.

Egwene looked down at the books with awe. Incredible! Light, but this was a treasure greater than any king's hoard. A treasure as great as the Horn of Valere itself. She looked up, tears in her eyes, imagining a life spent among the Black, always watching, recording, and working for the good of all.

"oʊ, doʊnt ɡoʊ duɪŋ ðæt," vɛɹɪn sɛd. hɝ feɪs wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə lʊk peɪl. "ðeɪ hæv mɛni eɪdʒəns əmʌŋ ʌs, laɪk wɝmz iɾɪŋ ðə fɹuɾ aʊt fɹəm ðə kɔɹ. wɛl, aɪ θɔɾ ɪt taɪm ðət wi hæɾ ət list wʌn ʌv əs əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðɪs ɪz wɝθ wʌn wʊmənz laɪf. fju pipəl əv hæɾ ə tʃæns tə kɹieɪt sʌmθɪŋ əz jusfəl, ən əz wʌndɝfəl, əz ðət bʊk jə hoʊld. wi ɔl sik tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə fjutʃɝ, ɛɡwin. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ maɪt dʒʌst əv ə tʃæns ət duɪŋ soʊ."

"Oh, don't go doing that," Verin said. Her face was beginning to look pale. "They have many agents among us, like worms eating the fruit out from the core. Well, I thought it time that we had at least one of us among them. This is worth one woman's life. Few people have had a chance to create something as useful, and as wonderful, as that book you hold. We all seek to change the future, Egwene. I think I might just have a chance at doing so."

vɛɹɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɝ hɛd. "maɪ. ðət dʌz wɝk kwɪkli. ðəɹ ɪz wʌn mɔɹ θɪŋ aɪ mʌs tɛl ju. oʊpən ðə ɹɛd bʊk, pliz."

Verin took a deep breath, then raised a hand to her head. "My. That does work quickly. There is one more thing I must tell you. Open the red book, please."

ɛɡwin dɪd soʊ, ən faʊn ə θɪn lɛðɝ stʃɹæp wɪð stil weɪts ɑn ði ɛnz, ðə taɪp juz fəɹ mɑɹkɪŋ wʌnz pleɪs ɪn ə bʊk, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz lɔŋɡɝ ðən ʌðɝz ʃi hæd sin.

Egwene did so, and found a thin leather strap with steel weights on the ends, the type used for marking one's place in a book, though it was longer than others she had seen.

"ɹæp ɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə bʊk," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "pleɪs ɪt mɑɹkɪŋ ɛni peɪdʒ, ðən twɪs ðə lus ɛnz ɝaʊn ðə tɑp."

"Wrap it around the book," Verin said, "place it marking any page, then twist the loose ends around the top."

ɛɡwin dɪd soʊ, kjʊɹiəs, tʌkɪŋ ðə stʃɹæp ɪndə ə ɹændəm peɪdʒ ən kloʊzɪŋ ðə bʊk. ʃi pʊt ðə smɔlɝ bʊk ɑn tɑp ə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ wʌn, ðən tʊk ðə lɔŋ ɛnz ə ðə bʊkmɑɹk ðət dæŋɡəl daʊn ən twɪstəɾ əm əbaʊt wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðə weɪts, ʃi noʊɾəst, fɪt təɡɛðɝ. ʃi lɑkt əm ɪndə pleɪs.

Egwene did so, curious, tucking the strap into a random page and closing the book. She put the smaller book on top of the larger one, then took the long ends of the bookmark that dangled down and twisted them about one another. The weights, she noticed, fit together. She locked them into place.

ən ðə bʊks vænɪʃt.

And the books vanished.

ɛɡwin stɛɹd. ʃi kəd stɪl fil əm ɪn əɹ hænz, bʌt ðə bʊks ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ ɪnvɪzəbəl.

Egwene stared. She could still feel them in her hands, but the books themselves were invisible.
