"oʊnli wɝks ɑn bʊks, aɪm əfɹeɪd," vɛɹɪn sɛd, jɔnɪŋ. "sʌmwʌn fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ɪɾ əpɪɹz, wɑz vɛɹi wɝiɾ əbaʊt haɪɾɪŋ ɪz əɹ əɹ dʒɝnəl fɹəm ʌðɝz." ʃi smaɪl slaɪtli, bʌt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ vɛɹi peɪl.

"Only works on books, I'm afraid," Verin said, yawning. "Someone from the Age of Legends, it appears, was very worried about hiding his or her journal from others." She smiled slightly, but was growing very pale.

"θæŋk ju, vɛɹɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd, ənklæspɪŋ ən ənɹæpɪŋ ðə bʊkmɑɹk. ðə vɑljumz əpɪɹɾ əɡɛn. "aɪ wɪʃ ðəɹ wɝ səm ʌðɝ weɪ . . ."

"Thank you, Verin," Egwene said, unclasping and unwrapping the bookmark. The volumes appeared again. "I wish there were some other way . . ."

"aɪ wɪl ədmɪt ðət ðə pɔɪzən wɑz ə bækʌp plæn," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ æm nɑɾ iɡɝ fəɹ dɛθ; ðəɹ ɑɹ stɪl θɪŋz aɪ nid tə du. fɔɹtʃənətli, aɪ hæv sɛt sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm ɪn moʊʃən tə bi . . . sin tə, ɪn keɪs aɪ də nɑt ɹɪtɝn. ɹəɡɑɹdləs, maɪ fɝs plæn wɑz tə faɪn ði oʊθ ɹɑd, ðən si ɪf aɪ kəd juz ɪt tə ɹimuv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz oʊðz. ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ əpɪɹz tə hæv ɡɔn mɪsɪŋ, ənfɔɹtʃənətli."

"I will admit that the poison was a backup plan," Verin said. "I am not eager for death; there are still things I need to do. Fortunately, I have set several of them in motion to be . . . seen to, in case I do not return. Regardless, my first plan was to find the Oath Rod, then see if I could use it to remove the Great Lord's oaths. The Oath Rod appears to have gone missing, unfortunately."

sɹɪn, ɛɡwin θɔt, ən ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ mʌst əv teɪkən ɪɾ əɡɛn. "aɪm sɑɹi, vɛɹɪn," ʃi sɛd.

Saerin, Egwene thought, and the others. They must have taken it again. "I'm sorry, Verin," she said.

"ɪt maɪt nɑɾ əv wɝkt ɛniweɪ," vɛɹɪn sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɑn ðə bɛd, ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ðə pɪloʊ bɪhaɪn əɹ stʃɹik bɹaʊn hɛɹ. "ðə pɹɑsɛs ə meɪkɪŋ ðoʊz oʊðz tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wɑz . . .

"It might not have worked anyway," Verin said, settling back on the bed, arranging the pillow behind her streaked brown hair. "The process of making those oaths to the Great Lord was . . .

dɪstɪŋktɪv. aɪ də wɪʃ aɪd bɪn eɪbəl tə dɪskʌvɝ wʌn mɔɹ tɪdbɪt fəɹ ju. wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən ɪz ɪn ðə taʊɝ, tʃaɪld. ɪts mɛsænə, aɪm sɝɾən ʌv ɪt. aɪ hæd hoʊp tə bi eɪbəl tə bɹɪŋ jə ðə neɪm ʃi wɑz haɪɾɪŋ ʌndɝ, bʌt ðə tu taɪmz aɪ mɛt wɪð hɝ, ʃi wɑz ʃɹaʊɾɪd tə ðə pɔɪn ðəɾ aɪ kʊdn tɛl. wʌɾ aɪ dɪd si ɪz ɹəkɔɹɾəd ɪn ðə ɹɛd bʊk.

distinctive. I do wish I'd been able to discover one more tidbit for you. One of the Chosen is in the Tower, child. It's Mesaana, I'm certain of it. I had hoped to be able to bring you the name she was hiding under, but the two times I met with her, she was shrouded to the point that I couldn't tell. What I did see is recorded in the red book.

"bi kɛɹfəl wɛɹ jə tʃɹɛd. bi kɛɹfəl haʊ jə stʃɹaɪk. əl liv ɪt tə jə tə dɪsaɪɾ ɪf jə wɑnə tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ ɔl ə ðɛm ət wʌns, əɹ ɪf jə wɑnə teɪk ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt wʌnz sɛpɝətli ɪn sikɹət. pɝhæps jəl dɪsaɪd tə wɑtʃ ən si ɪf jə kən kaʊntɝ ðɛɹ plɑts. ə ɡʊɾ ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃən maɪt jild laɪɾ əpɑn səm ə ðə kwɛstʃənz aɪ wɑz nɑɾ eɪbəl tə ænsɝ. soʊ mɛni dɪsɪʒənz jə mʌs meɪk, fəɹ wʌn soʊ jʌŋ." ʃi jɔnd, ðən ɡɹɪməst əz ə peɪn stæb hɝ.

"Be careful where you tread. Be careful how you strike. I will leave it to you to decide if you want to try to get all of them at once, or if you want to take the most important ones separately in secret. Perhaps you will decide to watch and see if you can counter their plots. A good interrogation might yield light upon some of the questions I was not able to answer. So many decisions you must make, for one so young." She yawned, then grimaced as a pain stabbed her.

ɛɡwin ɹoʊz, wɔkɪŋ tə vɛɹɪnz saɪd. "θæŋk ju, vɛɹɪn. θæŋk jə fəɹ tʃuzɪŋ mi tə kæɹi ðɪs bɝɾən."

Egwene rose, walking to Verin's side. "Thank you, Verin. Thank you for choosing me to carry this burden."

vɛɹɪn smaɪl feɪnli. "ju dɪd vɛɹi wɛl wɪð ðə pɹiviəs tɪdbɪts aɪ ɡeɪv ju. ðət wɑz kwaɪt ði ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ sɪtʃueɪʃən. ði æmɪɝlɪn kəmændəd ðəɾ aɪ ɡɪv jə ɪnfɝmeɪʃən tə hʌn ðə blæk sɪstɝz u flɛd ðə taʊɝ, soʊ aɪ hæd tə kəmplaɪ, ivən ðoʊ ðə liɾɝʃɪp ə ðə blæk wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd baɪ ði ɔɹɾɝ. aɪ wɑzn səpoʊz tə ɡɪv jə ðə dʒɹimɪŋ tɛɹæŋɡɹil, jə noʊ. bʌɾ aɪv ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə filɪŋ əbaʊt ju."

Verin smiled faintly. "You did very well with the previous tidbits I gave you. That was quite the interesting situation. The Amyrlin commanded that I give you information to hunt the Black sisters who fled the Tower, so I had to comply, even though the leadership of the Black was frustrated by the order. I wasn't supposed to give you the dreaming ter'angreal, you know. But I've always had a feeling about you."

"aɪm nɑt sɝɾən aɪ dɪzɝv sətʃ tʃɹʌst." ɛɡwin lʊk daʊn ət ðə bʊk. "tʃɹʌst sətʃ əz juv ʃoʊn."

"I'm not certain I deserve such trust." Egwene looked down at the book. "Trust such as you've shown."

"nɑnsɛns, tʃaɪld," vɛɹɪn sɛd, jɔnɪŋ əɡɛn, aɪz kloʊzɪŋ. "ju wɪl bi æmɪɝlɪn. aɪm kɑnfəɾənt ʌv ɪt. ən ən æmɪɝlɪn ʃəd bi wɛl ɑɹmd wɪð nɑlədʒ. ðæt, əmʌŋ ɔl θɪŋz, ɪz ðə moʊst seɪkɹəd duɾi ʌv ðə bɹaʊn - tə ɑɹm ðə wɝld wɪð nɑlədʒ. aɪm stɪl wʌn ə ðɛm. pliz si ðət ðeɪ noʊ, ɔlðoʊ ðə wɝd blæk meɪ bɹæn maɪ neɪm fɝɛvɝ, maɪ soʊl ɪz bɹaʊn. tɛl ðɛm. . . ."

"Nonsense, child," Verin said, yawning again, eyes closing. "You will be Amyrlin. I'm confident of it. And an Amyrlin should be well armed with knowledge. That, among all things, is the most sacred duty of the Brown - to arm the world with knowledge. I'm still one of them. Please see that they know, although the word Black may brand my name forever, my soul is Brown. Tell them. . . ."

"aɪ wɪl, vɛɹɪn," ɛɡwin pɹɑməst. "bʌt jəɹ soʊl ɪz nɑt bɹaʊn. aɪ kən si ɪt."

"I will, Verin," Egwene promised. "But your soul is not Brown. I can see it."

hɝ aɪz flʌɾɝd oʊpən, miɾɪŋ ɛɡwinz, ə fɹaʊn kɹisɪŋ əɹ fɔɹhɛd.

Her eyes fluttered open, meeting Egwene's, a frown creasing her forehead.

"jɔɹ soʊl ɪz ʌv ə pjʊɹ waɪt, vɛɹɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd sɔfli. "laɪk ðə laɪɾ ɪtsɛlf."

"Your soul is of a pure white, Verin," Egwene said softly. "Like the Light itself."

vɛɹɪn smaɪld, ən əɹ aɪz kloʊzd. ði æktʃəwəl dɛθ wɑz ə fju mɔɹ mɪnəts ɪn kʌmɪŋ, bʌɾ ʌnkɑnʃəsnəs keɪm fɝst ən swɪfli. ɛɡwin sæt, hoʊldɪŋ ðə wʊmənz hænd. ɪleɪɾə ən ðə hɔl kəd si tə ðɛmsɛlvz; ɛɡwin hæd pɹipɛɹɾ əɹ sidz wɛl. ʃoʊɪŋ ʌp naʊ ən meɪkɪŋ dɪmænz wəd bi tə oʊvɝɪkstɛn əɹ əθɔɹəɾi.

Verin smiled, and her eyes closed. The actual death was a few more minutes in coming, but unconsciousness came first and swiftly. Egwene sat, holding the woman's hand. Elaida and the Hall could see to themselves; Egwene had prepared her seeds well. Showing up now and making demands would be to overextend her authority.

æftɝ vɛɹɪnz pʌls feɪɾəd, ɛɡwin tʊk ðə kʌp ə pɔɪzən ti ən sɛɾ ɪɾ əsaɪd, ðən ɹeɪz ðə sɔsɝ ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə vɛɹɪnz noʊz. ðə ʃaɪni sɝfəs ɹəflɛktəd noʊ fɑɡ. ɪt fɛl kæləs tə dʌbəl-tʃɛk, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ səm pɔɪzənz wɪtʃ kəd meɪk wʌn əpɪɹ tə bi dɛɾ ən bɹið oʊnli vɛɹi ʃæloʊli, ən ɪf vɛɹɪn hæd wɑntəd tə tʃɹɪk ɛɡwin ən pɔɪn ə fɪŋɡɝ ət ðə ɹɔŋ sɪstɝz, ðɪs wʊɾə bɪn ə wʌndɝfəl mɛθəd. kæləs ɪndid tə dʌbəl-tʃɛk, ən ɪt meɪɾ ɛɡwin fil sɪk, bʌt ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn. ʃi dɪd ðət wɪtʃ wɑz dɪfəkəlt ən kənsɪɾɝd ɔl pɑsəbɪləɾiz.

After Verin's pulse faded, Egwene took the cup of poisoned tea and set it aside, then raised the saucer up in front of Verin's nose. The shiny surface reflected no fog. It felt callous to double-check, but there were some poisons which could make one appear to be dead and breathe only very shallowly, and if Verin had wanted to trick Egwene and point a finger at the wrong sisters, this would have been a wonderful method. Callous indeed to double-check, and it made Egwene feel sick, but she was Amyrlin. She did that which was difficult and considered all possibilities.

ʃʊɹli noʊ tʃɹuli blæk sɪstɝ wʊɾə bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə daɪ dʒʌs tə kɹieɪt sətʃ mɪsdɝɛkʃən. hɝ hɑɹt tʃɹʌstɪd vɛɹɪn, ɔlðoʊ hɝ maɪnd wɑntəd tə bi sɝɾən. ʃi ɡlæns təwɔɹɾ əɹ sɪmpəl dɛsk, wɛɹ ʃi hæd sɛt ðə bʊks. ət ðət moʊmənt, ðə dɔɹ tə hɝ ɹum oʊpənd wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ ən ə jʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ - nu ɪnʌf tə ðə ʃɔl ðəɾ əɹ feɪs dɪdnt ʃoʊ ði eɪdʒləs lʊk jɛt - pikt ɪn. tʊɹeɪzi, wʌn ə ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz. soʊ sʌmwʌn hæd faɪnəli bɪn əsaɪn tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ ɛɡwin. hɝ pɪɹiəɾ ə fɹiɾəm hæd kʌm tə ən ɛnd. wɛl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ jus kɹaɪɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌt kəɾ əv bɪn. ðə taɪm hæd bɪn wɛl spɛnt. ʃi wɪʃt vɛɹɪn hæd kʌm tə si hɝ ə wik ɝliɝ, bʌt wʌt wɑz dʌn wɑz dʌn.

Surely no truly Black sister would have been willing to die just to create such misdirection. Her heart trusted Verin, although her mind wanted to be certain. She glanced toward her simple desk, where she had set the books. At that moment, the door to her room opened without warning and a young Aes Sedai - new enough to the Shawl that her face didn't show the ageless look yet - peeked in. Turese, one of the Red sisters. So someone had finally been assigned to watch over Egwene. Her period of freedom had come to an end. Well, there was no use crying over what could have been. The time had been well spent. She wished Verin had come to see her a week earlier, but what was done was done.

ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ fɹaʊn ət siɪŋ vɛɹɪn, ən ɛɡwin kwɪkli ɹeɪzd ə fɪŋɡɝ tə hɝ lɪps ən ʃɑt ðə jʌŋ sɪstɝ ə hɑɹʃ lʊk.

The Red sister frowned at seeing Verin, and Egwene quickly raised a finger to her lips and shot the young sister a harsh look.

ɛɡwin hɝid tə ðə dɔɹ. "ʃi dʒʌst ɡɑɾ ɪn, ən wɪʃt tə spik tə mi ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ə tæsk ʃi hæd sɛt mi əpɑn lɔŋ əɡoʊ, bæk bɪfɔɹ ðə taʊɝ splɪt. ðeɪ kən bi ɑdli sɪŋɡəl-maɪndəɾ ət taɪmz, ðiz bɹaʊn sɪstɝz." tʃɹu wɝdz, ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm.

Egwene hurried to the door. "She just got in, and wished to speak to me regarding a task she had set me upon long ago, back before the Tower split. They can be oddly single-minded at times, these Brown sisters." True words, every one of them.

tʊɹeɪzi nɑɾəd ɹufəli ət ðə kɑmɛn əbaʊt bɹaʊnz.

Turese nodded ruefully at the comment about Browns.

"aɪ də wɪʃ ʃid tʃoʊzən əɹ oʊn bɛd tə laɪ daʊn ɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌt tə də wɪð əɹ naʊ." ɔl tʃɹu əɡɛn. ɛɡwin ɹɪli dɪd nid tə ɡɛɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ðəɾ oʊθ ɹɑd. laɪɪŋ stɑɹɾəd tə sim fɑɹ tu kənvinjən ət taɪmz laɪk ðɪs.

"I do wish she'd chosen her own bed to lie down in," Egwene said. "I'm not sure what to do with her now." All true again. Egwene really did need to get her hands on that Oath Rod. Lying started to seem far too convenient at times like this.

"ʃi mʌs bi taɪɝd fɹəm əɹ tʃɹævəlz," tʊɹeɪzi sɛd, vɔɪs sɑf bʌt fɝm. "ju lɛɾ əɹ də əz ʃi wɪʃɪz; ʃiz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən jə sɪmpli ə nɑvəs. də nɑt dɪstɝb hɝ."

"She must be tired from her travels," Turese said, voice soft but firm. "You let her do as she wishes; she is Aes Sedai, and you simply a novice. Do not disturb her."

wɪð ðæt, ðə ɹɛd kloʊz ðə dɔɹ, ən ɛɡwin smaɪl tə hɝsɛlf ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən. ðən ʃi ɡlænst ət vɛɹɪnz kɔɹps, ən ðə smaɪl feɪɾəd. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɹɪvil ðət vɛɹɪn hæd daɪd.

With that, the Red closed the door, and Egwene smiled to herself in satisfaction. Then she glanced at Verin's corpse, and the smile faded. Eventually, she would have to reveal that Verin had died.

haʊ wəd ʃi ɪkspleɪn ðæt? wɛl, ʃi wəd θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ. ɪf pɹɛst, ʃi maɪt dʒʌs tɛl ðə tʃɹuθ.

How would she explain that? Well, she would think of something. If pressed, she might just tell the truth.

fɝst, ðoʊ, ʃi niɾəd tə spɛn səm taɪm wɪð ðət bʊk. ðə tʃænsəz ʌv ɪt biɪŋ teɪkən fɹəm əɹ ɪn ðə nɪɹ fjutʃɝ wɝ ɡɹeɪt, ivən wɪð ðə bʊkmɑɹk tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ʃi ʃəd pɹɑbli stɔɹ ðə saɪfɝ sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə kənsil bʊk. pɝhæps mɛmɝaɪz ən dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə saɪfɝ. ðɪs wəɾ ɔl bi iziɝ tə plæn fəɹ ɪf ʃi nu haʊ ɪvɛns hæd ɡɔn ɪn ðə hɔl! hæɾ ɪleɪɾə bɪn dɪpoʊzd? wɑz sɪlviænə əlaɪv, əɹ hæd ʃi bɪn ɛksəkjuɾəd?

First, though, she needed to spend some time with that book. The chances of it being taken from her in the near future were great, even with the bookmark ter'angreal. She should probably store the cipher separate from the concealed book. Perhaps memorize and destroy the cipher. This would all be easier to plan for if she knew how events had gone in the Hall! Had Elaida been deposed? Was Silviana alive, or had she been executed?

ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl ʃi kəd dɪskʌvɝ naʊ, nɑt waɪl biɪŋ ɡɑɹɾəd. ʃi wəd sɪmpli hæv tə weɪt. ən ɹɛd.

There was little she could discover now, not while being guarded. She would simply have to wait. And read.

ðə koʊd pɹuv tə bi ɹæðɝ kɑmplɛks, ɹikwaɪɝɪŋ ə ɡʊd pɑɹɾ ə ðə smɔlɝ bʊk tə ɪkspleɪn. ðət wɑz boʊθ ædvənteɪdʒəs ən fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ. ɪt wəd bi vɛɹi dɪfəkəl tə bɹeɪk ðə koʊd wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt ðə koʊd wəɾ ɔlsoʊ bi nɪɹ ɪmpɑsəbəl tə mɛmɝaɪz. ʃi wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə mænədʒ ɪt bɪfɔɹ mɔɹnɪŋ, baɪ wɪtʃ taɪm ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɹɪvil vɛɹɪnz tʃɹu steɪt.

The code proved to be rather complex, requiring a good part of the smaller book to explain. That was both advantageous and frustrating. It would be very difficult to break the code without it, but the code would also be near impossible to memorize. She wouldn't be able to manage it before morning, by which time she would have to reveal Verin's true state.

ʃi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ət ðə wʊmən. vɛɹɪn ɹɪli dɪd lʊk əz ɪf ʃi wɝ slipɪŋ pisfəli. ɛɡwin hæd pʊld aʊt ðə blæŋkəɾ ən kʌvɝɾ əɹ ʌp tə ðə nɛk, ðən teɪkən ɔf əɹ ʃuz ən sɛɾ əm bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd tə ɛnhæns ði ɪluʒən. filɪŋ ə lɪɾəl dɪsɹɪspɛkfəl, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɹoʊl vɛɹɪn ɑntu hɝ saɪd.

She glanced over at the woman. Verin really did look as if she were sleeping peacefully. Egwene had pulled out the blanket and covered her up to the neck, then taken off her shoes and set them beside the bed to enhance the illusion. Feeling a little disrespectful, she decided to roll Verin onto her side.

ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pikt ɪn ə kʌpəl ə taɪmz, ən siɪŋ vɛɹɪn ɪn ənʌðɝ pəzɪʃən wəd lʊk lɛs səspɪʃəs.

The Red sister had already peeked in a couple of times, and seeing Verin in another position would look less suspicious.

ðət fɪnɪʃt, ɛɡwin ɡlænst əɾ əɹ kændəl tə dʒʌdʒ ðə pæsədʒ ə taɪm. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wɪndoʊz ɪn ðə ɹum, nɑɾ ɪn ə nɑvəsəz kɔɹɾɝz. ʃi ʃʌvd əsaɪd ðə lɔŋɪŋ tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə paʊɝ ən kɹieɪɾ ə bɔl ə laɪt baɪ wɪtʃ tə ɹid. ʃiɾ əv tə bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ðə sɪŋɡəl kændəlz fleɪm.

That finished, Egwene glanced at her candle to judge the passage of time. There were no windows in the room, not in a novice's quarters. She shoved aside the longing to embrace the Power and create a ball of light by which to read. She'd have to be satisfied with the single candle's flame.

ʃi dʌɡ ɪndə hɝ fɝs tæsk: dəsaɪfɝɪŋ ðə neɪmz ə ðə blæk sɪstɝz lɪstəɾ ət ðə bæk ə ðə toʊm. ðət wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ivən, ðən mɛmɝaɪzɪŋ ðə saɪfɝ. ʃi hæd tə noʊ hum ʃi kəd tʃɹʌst.

She dug into her first task: deciphering the names of the Black sisters listed at the back of the tome. That was more important, even, than memorizing the cipher. She had to know whom she could trust.

ðə nɛks fju aʊɝz wɝ əmʌŋ ðə moʊs dɪstɝbɪŋ ən dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ laɪf. səm ə ðə neɪmz wɝ ənnoʊn tə hɝ, mɛni bɛɹli fəmɪljɝ. ʌðɝz wɝ wɪmən ʃi hæd wɝkt wɪð, ɹɪspɛktɪd, ən ivən tʃɹʌstɪd. ʃi kɝst wən ʃi faʊn keɪɾɝinz neɪm nɪɹ ðə hɛɾ ə ðə lɪst, ðən hɪst ɪn sɝpɹaɪz wən ɑlviɛɝɪnz neɪm keɪm ʌp. ʃid hɝɾ ʌv ɛlzə pɛnfəl ən ɡəlinə kæsbən, ðoʊ ʃi dɪdnt noʊ səm ə ðə nɛks fju neɪmz.

The next few hours were among the most disturbing and discomforting in her life. Some of the names were unknown to her, many barely familiar. Others were women she had worked with, respected, and even trusted. She cursed when she found Katerine's name near the head of the list, then hissed in surprise when Alviarin's name came up. She'd heard of Elza Penfell and Galina Casban, though she didn't know some of the next few names.

ʃi fɛlt ə sɪkənɪŋ pɪt wɪðɪn əɹ wən ʃi ɹɛd ʃɛɹiəmz neɪm. ɛɡwin hæd wʌns səspɛktəd ðə wʊmən, tʃɹu, bʌt ðət hæd bɪn dʊɹɪŋ əɹ deɪz əz ə nɑvəs ən ən æksɛptɪd. dʊɹɪŋ ðoʊz deɪz - ðə deɪz wən ʃid fɝs bɪɡʌn hʌntɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ - liɑnʒɹɪnz bɪtʃɹeɪəl hæd stɪl bɪn fɹɛʃ. ɛɡwin hæd səspɛktəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ðɛn.

She felt a sickening pit within her when she read Sheriam's name. Egwene had once suspected the woman, true, but that had been during her days as a novice and an Accepted. During those days - the days when she'd first begun hunting the Black Ajah - Liandrin's betrayal had still been fresh. Egwene had suspected everyone then.

dʊɹɪŋ ði ɛɡzaɪl ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, ɛɡwin hæd wɝkt kloʊsli wɪð ʃɛɹiəm ən hæd ɡɹoʊn tə laɪk ðə wʊmən. bʌt ʃi wɑz blæk. ɛɡwinz oʊn kipɝ wɑz blæk. stil jɝsɛlf, ɛɡwin, ʃi θɔt, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə ɹid daʊn ðə lɪst. ʃi wɝk θɹu ðə filɪŋz ə bɪtʃɹeɪəl, ðə bɪɾɝnəs ən ðə ɹəɡɹɛt. ʃi wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɪmoʊʃənz ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv əɹ duɾi.

During the exile in Salidar, Egwene had worked closely with Sheriam and had grown to like the woman. But she was Black. Egwene's own Keeper was Black. Steel yourself, Egwene, she thought, continuing to read down the list. She worked through the feelings of betrayal, the bitterness and the regret. She would not let emotions get in the way of her duty.

ðə blæk sɪstɝz wɝ spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ɔl ədʒəz. səm wɝ sɪɾɝz, ʌðɝz wɝ ðə loʊəst ən lis paʊɝfəl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ðəɹ wɝ hʌnʒɹədz ə ðɛm, ə lɪɾəl oʊvɝ tu hʌnʒɹəd baɪ vɛɹɪnz oʊn kaʊnt. twɛnti-wʌn ɪn ðə blu, twɛnti-eɪɾ ɪn ðə bɹaʊn, θɝɾi ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ, θɝɾi-eɪt ɪn ðə ɡɹin, sɛvəntin ɪn ðə waɪt, twɛnti-wʌn ɪn ðə jɛloʊ, ən ə stʌnɪŋ fɔɹɾi-eɪt ɪn ðə ɹɛd. ðəɹ wɝ neɪmz ʌv æksɛptɪɾ ən nɑvəsɪz əz wɛl. ðə bʊk noʊɾəd ðət ðoʊz hæd pɹɑbli bɪn dɑɹkfɹɛnz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dʒɔɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, əz ðə blæk ədʒɑ dɪd nɑt ɹəkɹut fɹəm ɛni ɪksɛpt ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt ɹəfɝɾ əɹ tə ən ɝliɝ peɪdʒ fəɹ ə lɔŋɡɝ ɛkspləneɪʃən, bʌɾ ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə lɪst ə sɪstɝz. ʃi niɾəd tə noʊ ðə neɪmz ʌv itʃ wʊmən. ʃi niɾəd tə.

The Black sisters were spread across all Ajahs. Some were Sitters, others were the lowest and least powerful of Aes Sedai. And there were hundreds of them, a little over two hundred by Verin's own count. Twenty-one in the Blue, twenty-eight in the Brown, thirty in the Gray, thirty-eight in the Green, seventeen in the White, twenty-one in the Yellow, and a stunning forty-eight in the Red. There were names of Accepted and novices as well. The book noted that those had probably been Darkfriends before they joined the White Tower, as the Black Ajah did not recruit from any except Aes Sedai. It referred her to an earlier page for a longer explanation, but Egwene continued down the list of sisters. She needed to know the names of each woman. She needed to.

ðəɹ wɝ blæk sɪstɝz əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðoʊz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ivən səm əmʌŋ ðoʊz ənælaɪn u hæd bɪn əweɪ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ dʊɹɪŋ ðə splɪt. ʌðɝ ðən ʃɛɹiəm, ðə moʊs dɪstɝbɪŋ dɪskʌvɝi ɑn ðə lɪst wɝ ðə sɪstɝz u wɝ sɪɾɝz ɪn iðɝ ðə taʊɝ əɹ əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəlz. dʌɑɹə bəseɪhin. vɛlinə bɛhɝ. sɛdɔɹi dæjɛnə. dɛlænə moʊzɑleɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, ən tælin mɪnli əz wɛl. maɪdɑni hæɾ ədmɪɾəd tə ɛɡwin ɪn kɑnfəɾəns ðət tælin wɑz ðə mɛmbɝ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ ðət sɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz hæd dɪskʌvɝd, bʌt ʃi hæd flɛd ðə taʊɝ.

There were Black sisters among the rebel Aes Sedai and those of the White Tower, and even some among those unaligned who had been away from the Tower during the split. Other than Sheriam, the most disturbing discovery on the list were the sisters who were Sitters in either the Tower or among the rebels. Duhara Basaheen. Velina Behar. Sedore Dajenna. Delana Mosalaine, of course, and Talene Minly as well. Meidani had admitted to Egwene in confidence that Talene was the member of the Black Ajah that Saerin and the others had discovered, but she had fled the Tower.

mɔɹiə kɛɹɛntənɪs. ðət læst wɑz ə mɛmbɝ ə ðə blu ədʒɑ, ə wʊmən u hæd wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl fəɹ oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, noʊn fəɹ əɹ wɪzdəm ən lɛvəl-hɛɾədnəs. ɛɡwin hæd kənfɝd wɪð əɹ ɑn numɝəs əkeɪʒənz, ən hæd dʒɹɔn ɑn əɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns, əsumɪŋ ðət ʃi - ə blu - wəd bi wʌn ə ðə moʊst ɹɪlaɪəbəl ɪn əɹ səpɔɹt. mɔɹiə hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæd bɪn iɡɝ tə ɪlɛkt ɛɡwin əz æmɪɝlɪn, ən hæd stʊd kwɪkli ɪn ɛɡwinz feɪvɝ ət sɛvɹəl kɹuʃəl moʊməns.

Moria Karentanis. That last was a member of the Blue Ajah, a woman who had worn the shawl for over a hundred years, known for her wisdom and level-headedness. Egwene had conferred with her on numerous occasions, and had drawn on her experience, assuming that she - a Blue - would be one of the most reliable in her support. Moria had been one of those who had been eager to elect Egwene as Amyrlin, and had stood quickly in Egwene's favor at several crucial moments.

itʃ neɪm wɑz laɪk ə θɔɹn θɹu ɛɡwinz skɪn. dæɡdɑɹə fɪntʃi, hu hæd hild ɛɡwin wʌns wən ʃid stʌmbəld ən twɪstəɾ əɹ æŋkəl. zænɪkə, hu hæd tɔɾ ɛɡwin lɛsənz ən hæd sim soʊ plɛzənt. lɑɹisə lɪndəl. mijɑsi, fəɹ hum ɛɡwin hæd kɹæk nʌts. nɛziɾə. nætʃɛl kjɑmə. næleɪin fɔɹeɪl, hu - laɪk ɛlzə - wɑz baʊn tə ɹænd. bɝlən pɛnə. mɛlvɑɹə. tʃaɪ ɹuɡən. . . .

Each name was like a thorn through Egwene's skin. Dagdara Finchey, who had healed Egwene once when she'd stumbled and twisted her ankle. Zanica, who had taught Egwene lessons and had seemed so pleasant. Larissa Lyndel. Miyasi, for whom Egwene had cracked nuts. Nesita. Nacelle Kayama. Nalaene Forrell, who - like Elza - was bound to Rand. Birlen Pena. Melvara. Chai Rugan. . . .

ðə lɪst wɛn ɑn. niðɝ ɹoʊmændə əɹ ləleɪn wɝ blæk, wɪtʃ wɑz sʌmwʌɾ ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ. biɪŋ eɪbəl tə θɹoʊ wʌn əɹ boʊθ ə ðoʊz ɪndə tʃeɪnz wʊɾə bɪn vɛɹi kənvinjənt. waɪ ʃɛɹiəm, bʌt niðɝ ə ðoʊz tu?

The list went on. Neither Romanda or Lelaine were Black, which was somewhat irritating. Being able to throw one or both of those into chains would have been very convenient. Why Sheriam, but neither of those two?

stɑp ɪt, ɛɡwin, ʃi θɔt. jə ɑɹən bɪheɪvɪŋ ɹæʃənəli. wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ sɝɾən sɪstɝz tə bi blæk ɡɑɾ əɹ noʊwɛɹ.

Stop it, Egwene, she thought. You aren't behaving rationally. Wishing for certain sisters to be Black got her nowhere.

kædzueɪn wɑz nɑɾ ɑn ðə lɪst. niðɝ wɝ ɛni ʌv ɛɡwinz dɪɹəs fɹɛnz. ʃi hædn ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə bi, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ɡʊd tə kəmplit ðə lɪst wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ɛni ʌv ðɛɹ neɪmz. ðə ɡɹup hʌntɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɹɪli wɑz tʃɹu, əz nʌn ə ðɛɹ neɪmz wɝ ɑn ðə lɪst.

Cadsuane was not on the list. Neither were any of Egwene's dearest friends. She hadn't expected them to be, but it was still good to complete the list without seeing any of their names. The group hunting the Black Ajah in the White Tower really was true, as none of their names were on the list.

ðə lɪst ɔlsoʊ dɪdn kənteɪn ðə neɪmz ʌv ɛni ʌv ðə spaɪz sɛn fɹəm sɑlədɑɹ.

The list also didn't contain the names of any of the spies sent from Salidar.

ən ɪleɪɾəz neɪm wɑzn ɑn ðə lɪst iðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz ə noʊteɪʃən ət ði ɛnd, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ðət vɛɹɪn hæd lʊk vɛɹi kloʊsli əɾ ɪleɪɾə, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ pɹuf ðət ʃi wɑz blæk. bʌt kɑmɛns baɪ blæk sɪstɝz lɛɾ əɹ tə bɪliv stʃɹɔŋli ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑz nɑt hɝsɛlf blæk. dʒʌst ən ənsteɪbəl wʊmən u wɑz səmtaɪmz əz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ tə ðə blæk əz ʃi wɑz tə ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taʊɝ.

And Elaida's name wasn't on the list either. There was a notation at the end, explaining that Verin had looked very closely at Elaida, searching for proof that she was Black. But comments by Black sisters led her to believe strongly that Elaida was not herself Black. Just an unstable woman who was sometimes as frustrating to the Black as she was to the rest of the Tower.

ɪt meɪd sɛns, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. noʊɪŋ ðət ɡəlinə ən ɑlviɛɝɪn wɝ blæk hæd lɛɾ ɛɡwin tə səspɛk ðət ʃi wʊdn faɪn ɪleɪɾəz neɪm ɑn ðə lɪst. ðə blæks simd mɔɹ laɪkli tə tʃuz sʌmwʌn ðeɪ kəd mənɪpjəleɪt tə bi æmɪɝlɪn, ðən ɪnstɔl ə blæk kipɝ tə kip əɹ ɪn laɪn.

It made sense, unfortunately. Knowing that Galina and Alviarin were Black had led Egwene to suspect that she wouldn't find Elaida's name on the list. The Blacks seemed more likely to choose someone they could manipulate to be Amyrlin, then install a Black Keeper to keep her in line.

ðeɪ pɹɑbli hæd juz səm kaɪndə lɛvɝɪdʒ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə θɹu ɡəlinə - hum vɛɹɪn noʊɾəd hæd pɹɑbli mænədʒ tə meɪk hɝsɛlf hɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ - əɹ ɑlviɛɝɪn. ðeɪ hæd bʊliɾ əɹ bɹaɪbd ɪleɪɾə tə də əz ðeɪ wɪʃt wɪθaʊɾ əɹ noʊɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz sɝvɪŋ ðə blæk. ən ðət hɛlpt ɪkspleɪn ɑlviɛɝɪnz stʃɹeɪnʒ fɔl. hæd ʃi ɡɔn tu fɑɹ, pɝhæps? oʊvɝstɛp hɝsɛlf, ɝnɪŋ ɪleɪɾəz aɪɹ? ɪt sim plɔzəbəl, ðoʊ ðeɪ wʊdnt noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən əntɪl ɪleɪɾə spoʊk əɹ ɛɡwin kəɾ əv ɑlviɛɝɪn ɪntɛɹəɡeɪɾɪd. wɪtʃ ʃi mɛn tə də əz sun əz pɑsəbəl.

They probably had used some kind of leverage against Elaida through Galina - whom Verin noted had probably managed to make herself Head of the Red Ajah - or Alviarin. They had bullied or bribed Elaida to do as they wished without her knowing that she was serving the Black. And that helped explain Alviarin's strange fall. Had she gone too far, perhaps? Overstepped herself, earning Elaida's ire? It seemed plausible, though they wouldn't know for certain until Elaida spoke or Egwene could have Alviarin interrogated. Which she meant to do as soon as possible.

ʃi kloʊz ðə fæt ɹɛd bʊk, θɔtfəl, hɝ kændəl bɝnd nɪɹli daʊn tə ðə beɪs. ɪt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ leɪɾ ɪn ðə deɪ. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɪnsɪst ɑn biɪŋ ɡɪvən səm ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əbaʊt ðə steɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ.

She closed the fat red book, thoughtful, her candle burned nearly down to the base. It was growing late in the day. Perhaps it was time to insist on being given some information about the state of the Tower.

bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd dɪsaɪd haʊ tə ɡoʊ əbaʊt ðæt, ə nɑk keɪm ət ðə dɔɹ. ɛɡwin lʊkt ʌp, hɝidli twɪstɪŋ ðə stʃɹæps ə ðə bʊkmɑɹk ɝaʊn ən meɪkɪŋ boʊθ bʊks vænɪʃ. ə nɑk mɛn sʌmwʌn ʌðɝ ðən ə ɹɛd wɑz ðɛɹ.

Before she could decide how to go about that, a knock came at the door. Egwene looked up, hurriedly twisting the straps of the bookmark around and making both books vanish. A knock meant someone other than a Red was there.

"kʌm," ʃi kɔld.

"Come," she called.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən tə ɹɪvil nɪkoʊlə, wɪð əɹ lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz ən slɛndɝ bɪld, stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪd bɪniθ ðə wɑtʃfəl aɪ ʌv tʊɹeɪzi. ðə ɹɛd dɪd nɑt sim pliz ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæɾ ə vɪzəɾɝ, bʌt ðə stimɪŋ boʊl kæɹiɾ ɑn nɪkoʊləz tʃɹeɪ ɪndəkeɪɾəd waɪ ʃid bɪn ɡɪvən liv tə nɑk.

The door opened to reveal Nicola, with her large dark eyes and slender build, standing outside beneath the watchful eye of Turese. The Red did not seem pleased that Egwene had a visitor, but the steaming bowl carried on Nicola's tray indicated why she'd been given leave to knock.

nɪkoʊlə kɝtsid tə ɛɡwin, hɝ waɪt nɑvəs dʒɹɛs flʌɾɝɪŋ. tʊɹeɪziz skaʊl dipənd. nɪkoʊlə dɪdnt noʊɾəs, haʊɛvɝ. "fɔɹ vɛɹɪn sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, nɑɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə bɛd. "baɪ ɔɹɾɝz ə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə kɪtʃənz, æftɝ hɪɹɪŋ haʊ ɪɡzɔstəd vɛɹɪn sədaɪ wɑz fɹəm əɹ tʃɹævəlz."

Nicola curtsied to Egwene, her white novice dress fluttering. Turese's scowl deepened. Nicola didn't notice, however. "For Verin Sedai," she said softly, nodding toward the bed. "By orders of the Mistress of Kitchens, after hearing how exhausted Verin Sedai was from her travels."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə teɪbəl, haɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɪksaɪtmənt. nɪkoʊlə əpɹoʊtʃt kwɪkli, sɛɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, wɪspɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, "aɪm tə æsk ɪf jə tʃɹʌs hɝ." ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə bɛɾ əɡɛn.

Egwene nodded, gesturing toward the table, hiding her excitement. Nicola approached quickly, setting the tray on the table, whispering under her breath, "I'm to ask if you trust her." She glanced at the bed again.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin ænsɝd, kʌvɝɪŋ ðə saʊn baɪ skuɾɪŋ əɹ stul bæk. soʊ hɝ ælaɪz dɪdnt noʊ ðət vɛɹɪn wɑz dɛd. ðət wɑz ɡʊd; ðə sikɹət wɑz stɪl seɪf, fəɹ ðə moʊmənt.

"Yes," Egwene answered, covering the sound by scooting her stool back. So her allies didn't know that Verin was dead. That was good; the secret was still safe, for the moment.

nɪkoʊlə nɑɾəd, ðən spoʊk ɪn ə laʊɾɝ vɔɪs. "ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd fəɹ əɹ tə iɾ ɪt wən ɪts wɔɹm, ðoʊ əl liv ɪt tə jə ɪf jə wɪʃ nɑt tə weɪk hɝ. aɪm ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə wɔɹn jə nɑt tə tʌtʃ ɪt jɝsɛlf."

Nicola nodded, then spoke in a louder voice. "It would be good for her to eat it when it's warm, though I'll leave it to you if you wish not to wake her. I'm instructed to warn you not to touch it yourself."

"aɪ woʊn də soʊ ənlɛs ɪt tɝnz aʊt ðət ʃiz noʊ niɾ ʌv ɪt," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ, ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪnd nɪkoʊlə. ɛɡwin weɪɾəd ə peɪnfəl fju mɪnəts fəɹ tʊɹeɪzi tə oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən tʃɛk ɑn hɝ, pæsɪŋ ðə taɪm baɪ wɑʃɪŋ əɹ feɪs ən hænz, ən pʊɾɪŋ ɑn ə klin dʒɹɛs. faɪnəli, kɑnfəɾənt ʃi wʊdn bi ɪntɝʌptɪd, ʃi ɡɹæb ðə spun ən fɪʃt ɪn ðə sup. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, ʃi faʊn ə smɔl ɡlæs vaɪəl wɪð ə ɹoʊld-ʌp pis ə peɪpɝ ɪn ɪt.

"I won't do so unless it turns out that she has no need of it," Egwene replied, turning away. A few moments later, the door closed behind Nicola. Egwene waited a painful few minutes for Turese to open the door and check on her, passing the time by washing her face and hands, and putting on a clean dress. Finally, confident she wouldn't be interrupted, she grabbed the spoon and fished in the soup. Sure enough, she found a small glass vial with a rolled-up piece of paper in it.

klɛvɝ. hɝ ælaɪz hæɾ əpɛɹənli hɝɾ ə vɛɹɪnz pɹɛzəns ɪn ɛɡwinz ɹum ən dɪsaɪɾɪd tə juz ɪɾ əz ən ɪkskjus tə ɡɛt sʌmwʌn ɪn. ʃi ənɹoʊl ðə peɪpɝ, wɪtʃ kənteɪn oʊnli wʌn wɝd.

Clever. Her allies had apparently heard of Verin's presence in Egwene's room and decided to use it as an excuse to get someone in. She unrolled the paper, which contained only one word.

"weɪt."

"Wait."

ʃi saɪd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə du. ʃi dɪdn dɛɹ ɡɛɾ aʊt ðə bʊk ən kəntɪnju ɹɛɾɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ. sun, ʃi hɝd vɔɪsəz aʊtsaɪd, ən wʌt saʊndəd laɪk ən ɑɹɡjəmənt. ənʌðɝ nɑk keɪm ət ðə dɔɹ.

She sighed, but there was nothing to do. She didn't dare get out the book and continue reading, however. Soon, she heard voices outside, and what sounded like an argument. Another knock came at the door.

"kʌm," ɛɡwin sɛd, kjʊɹiəs.

"Come," Egwene said, curious.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ən maɪdɑni stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum. ʃi pɔɪntɪdli kloʊz ðə dɔɹ ɑn tʊɹeɪzi.

The door opened and Meidani stepped into the room. She pointedly closed the door on Turese.

"mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd, kɝtsiɪŋ. ðə slɛndɝ wʊmən wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə taɪt ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs wɪtʃ pʊld ə lɪɾəl tu ɑbviəsli əkɹɔs əɹ æmpəl tʃɛst. hæd ʃi bɪn skɛdʒʊl fəɹ ə dɪnɝ wɪð ɪleɪɾə ðɪs ivnɪŋ? "aɪ æm sɑɹi tə kip jə weɪɾɪŋ."

"Mother," she said, curtsying. The slender woman was wearing a tight gray dress which pulled a little too obviously across her ample chest. Had she been scheduled for a dinner with Elaida this evening? "I am sorry to keep you waiting."

ɛɡwin weɪv dɪsmɪsɪvli. "haʊ dɪd jə ɡɛt pæs tʊɹeɪzi?"

Egwene waved dismissively. "How did you get past Turese?"

"ɪɾ ɪz noʊn ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə . . . feɪvɝz mi wɪð vɪzəts," ʃi sɛd. "æn taʊɝ lɔ sɛz ðət noʊ pɹɪznɝ kən bi fɔɹbɪɾən vɪzəɾɝz. ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp ə sɪstɝ fɹəm wɪʃɪŋ tə vɪzəɾ ə sɪmpəl nɑvəs, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk ə pɔɪn ʌv ɑɹɡjuɪŋ ɪt."

"It is known that Elaida . . . favors me with visits," she said. "And Tower law says that no prisoner can be forbidden visitors. She could not stop a sister from wishing to visit a simple novice, though she did try to make a point of arguing it."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd, ən maɪdɑni ɡlænst ət vɛɹɪn, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ðən ʃi peɪld. vɛɹɪnz fitʃɝz hæd ɡɹoʊn wæksi ən dʌl, ən ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ðət sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ðət tʊɹeɪzi hæd nɛvɝ lʊkt kloʊsli ət ðə "slipɪŋ" wʊmən.

Egwene nodded, and Meidani glanced at Verin, frowning. Then she paled. Verin's features had grown waxy and dull, and it was obvious that something was wrong. It was a good thing that Turese had never looked closely at the "sleeping" woman.

"vɛɹɪn sədaɪ ɪz dɛd," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ.

"Verin Sedai is dead," Egwene said, glancing at the door.

"mʌðɝ?" maɪdɑni æskt. "wʌt hæpənd? wɝ jə ətækt?"

"Mother?" Meidani asked. "What happened? Were you attacked?"

"vɛɹɪn sədaɪ wɑz pɔɪzən baɪ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd ʃɔɹtli bɪfɔɹ əɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð mi. ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ə ðə pɔɪzən, ən keɪm tə pæs ɑn səm ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnfɝmeɪʃən tə mi dʊɹɪŋ əɹ læs moʊməns."

"Verin Sedai was poisoned by a Darkfriend shortly before her conversation with me. She was aware of the poison, and came to pass on some important information to me during her last moments."

ɪt wɑz ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl wʌɾ ə fju tʃɹu steɪtməns kəd kənsil.

It was incredible what a few true statements could conceal.

"laɪt!" maɪdɑni sɛd. "ə mɝɾɝ ɪnsaɪd ðə waɪt taʊɝ? wɪv tə tɛl sʌmwʌn! ɡæðɝ ðə ɡɑɹɾ ən - "

"Light!" Meidani said. "A murder inside the White Tower? We have to tell someone! Gather the guard and - "

"ɪt wɪl bi dɛlt wɪð," ɛɡwin sɛd fɝmli. "kip jəɹ vɔɪs daʊn ən pʊl jɝsɛlf təɡɛðɝ. aɪ doʊnt wɑn ðə ɡɑɹɾ aʊtsaɪd tə hɪɹ wʌt wəɹ seɪɪŋ."

"It will be dealt with," Egwene said firmly. "Keep your voice down and pull yourself together. I don't want the guard outside to hear what we are saying."

maɪdɑni peɪld, ðən lʊkt əɾ ɛɡwin, laɪkli wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ ʃi kəd bi soʊ kæləs. ɡʊd. lɛɾ əɹ si ðə kəlɛktəd, dɪtɝmən æmɪɝlɪn. əz lɔŋ əz ʃi dɪdn si ə hɪn ə ðə ɡɹif, kənfjuʒən ən æŋzaɪəɾi ɪnsaɪd.

Meidani paled, then looked at Egwene, likely wondering how she could be so callous. Good. Let her see the collected, determined Amyrlin. As long as she didn't see a hint of the grief, confusion and anxiety inside.

"jɛs, mʌðɝ." maɪdɑni kɝtsid. "ʌv kɔɹs. aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz."

"Yes, Mother." Meidani curtsied. "Of course. I apologize."

"naʊ, jə bɹɪŋ nuz, aɪ əsum?"

"Now, you bring news, I assume?"

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," maɪdɑni sɛd, kəmpoʊzɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "sɹɪn ɪnstʃɹʌktəd mi tə kʌm tə ju. ʃi sɛd jə wəd nid tə noʊ ʌv ðə deɪz ɪvɛns."

"Yes, Mother," Meidani said, composing herself. "Saerin instructed me to come to you. She said you would need to know of the day's events."

"æn aɪ du," ɛɡwin sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə ʃoʊ hɝ ɪmpeɪʃəns. laɪt, bʌt ʃiɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn eɪbəl tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt ðət pɑɹt. kʊdn ðə wʊmən ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt? ðəɹ wɝ blæk ədʒɑ tə dil wɪð!

"And I do," Egwene said, trying not to show her impatience. Light, but she'd already been able to figure out that part. Couldn't the woman get on with it? There were Black Ajah to deal with!

"ɪleɪɾə ɪz stɪl æmɪɝlɪn," maɪdɑni sɛd, "bʌɾ oʊnli baɪ ə hɛɹ. ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ mɛɾ ən sɛnʃɝɾ əɹ fɔɹməli. ðeɪ ɪnfɔɹmd ɪleɪɾə ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz nɑɾ ən æbsəlut ɹulɝ, ən ðət ʃi kʊdn kəntɪnju tə meɪk dɪkɹiz ən dɪmænz wɪθaʊt kənsʌltɪŋ ðɛm."

"Elaida is still Amyrlin," Meidani said, "but only by a hair. The Hall of the Tower met and censured her formally. They informed Elaida that the Amyrlin was not an absolute ruler, and that she couldn't continue to make decrees and demands without consulting them."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. "nɑɾ ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd tɝn," ʃi sɛd. mɔɹ ðən wʌn æmɪɝlɪn hæd bɪkʌm oʊnli ə fɪɡjɝhɛd kəz ʃiɾ oʊvɝɪkstɛndəd hɝsɛlf ɪn ə sɪməlɝ weɪ. ɪt wɑz wʌɾ ɪleɪɾə hæd bɪn hɛɾɪŋ fɔɹ, ən ðət wʊɾə bɪn sæɾəsfæktʃɹi, hæd ðiz nɑt bɪn ði ɛn ə deɪz. "wʌɾ ə pɛnəns?"

Egwene nodded. "Not an unexpected turn," she said. More than one Amyrlin had become only a figurehead because she'd overextended herself in a similar way. It was what Elaida had been heading for, and that would have been satisfactory, had these not been the end of days. "What of penance?"

"θɹi mʌnθs," maɪdɑni sɛd. "wʌn fəɹ wʌt ʃi dɪd tə ju. tu fəɹ bɪheɪvjɝ ʌnbɪkʌmɪŋ əɹ steɪʃən."

"Three months," Meidani said. "One for what she did to you. Two for behavior unbecoming her station."

"ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd, θɔtfəl.

"Interesting," Egwene said, thoughtful.

"ðɛɹ wɝ səm u kɔl fəɹ mɔɹ, mʌðɝ. ɪt sim ðət fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi maɪt bi dɪpoʊzd ɹaɪt ðɛɹ."

"There were some who called for more, Mother. It seemed that for a moment she might be deposed right there."

"ju wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ?" ɛɡwin æskt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz.

"You were watching?" Egwene asked with surprise.

maɪdɑni nɑɾəd. "ɪleɪɾə æsk fəɹ ðə pɹoʊsiɾɪŋz tə bi sil tə ðə fleɪm, bʌt ʃi ɡeɪnd noʊ səpɔɹɾ ɪn ðə muv. aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ əɹ oʊn ədʒɑ wɑz bɪhaɪn ðæt, mʌðɝ. ɔl θɹi ʌv ðə ɹɛdz sɪɾɝz ɑɹ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ. aɪ stɪl wʌndɝ wɛɹ dʌɑɹə ən ði ʌðɝz wɛnt."

Meidani nodded. "Elaida asked for the proceedings to be Sealed to the Flame, but she gained no support in the move. I think that her own Ajah was behind that, Mother. All three of the Red's Sitters are out of the Tower. I still wonder where Duhara and the others went."

dʌɑɹə. eɪ blæk. wʌɾ ɪz ʃi ʌp tə? ən ði ʌðɝ tu? wɝ ðə θɹi təɡɛðɝ, ən ɪf soʊ, kəd ði ʌðɝ tu bi blæk əz wɛl?

Duhara. A Black. What is she up to? And the other two? Were the three together, and if so, could the other two be Black as well?

ʃiɾ əv tə ædʒɹɛs ðət leɪɾɝ. "haʊ dɪɾ ɪleɪɾə teɪk ɔl ə ðɪs?"

She'd have to address that later. "How did Elaida take all of this?"

"ʃi dɪdn seɪ mʌtʃ, mʌðɝ," maɪdɑni sɛd. "ʃi sæɾ ən wɑtʃt, moʊsli. ʃi dɪdn lʊk vɛɹi plizd; aɪ wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ʃi dɪdn stɑɹt ɹæntɪŋ."

"She didn't say much, Mother," Meidani said. "She sat and watched, mostly. She didn't look very pleased; I was surprised she didn't start ranting."

"ðə ɹɛdz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ɪf ʃiz ɹɪli luzɪŋ səpɔɹɾ ɪn əɹ oʊn ədʒɑ, ðeɪɾ əv wɔɹn əɹ əhɛɾ ə taɪm nɑt tə meɪk mɔɹ weɪvz."

"The Reds," Egwene said. "If she is really losing support in her own Ajah, they'd have warned her ahead of time not to make more waves."

"ðæt wɑz sɹɪnz əsɛsmən əz wɛl," maɪdɑni ɹɪplaɪd. "ʃi ɔlsoʊ noʊɾəd ðət jəɹ oʊn ɪnsɪstəns ðət ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ nɑt bi əlaʊd tə fɔl - spɹɛd baɪ ə ɡɹup ə nɑvəsɪz u oʊvɝhɝd ju  - wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt kɛpt ɪleɪɾə fɹəm biɪŋ dɪpoʊzd."

"That was Saerin's assessment as well," Meidani replied. "She also noted that your own insistence that the Red Ajah not be allowed to fall - spread by a group of novices who overheard you  - was part of what kept Elaida from being deposed."

"wɛl, aɪ wʊdn maɪn əɹ dɪpoʊzd," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ dʒʌs dɪdnt wɑn ði ɪntaɪɝ ədʒɑ dɪsbændɪd.

"Well, I wouldn't mind her deposed," Egwene said. "I just didn't want the entire Ajah disbanded.

stɪl, ðɪs maɪt bi fəɹ ðə bɛst. ɪleɪɾəz fɔl əz tə kʌm ɪn ə weɪ ðət dʌzn tɛɹ ðə taʊɝ daʊn wɪð hɝ." ðoʊ, ɪf ɛɡwin kəd də ɪɾ əɡɛn, ʃi maɪt ɹitʃɹæk ðoʊz wɝdz sɛɾ ɝliɝ. ʃi dɪdnt wɑn ɛniwʌn tə θɪŋk ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd bɪn səpɔɹɾɪŋ ɪleɪɾə. "aɪ əsum ðət sɪlviænəz sɛntəns əz bɪn dɪsmɪst?"

Still, this might be for the best. Elaida's fall has to come in a way that doesn't tear the Tower down with her." Though, if Egwene could do it again, she might retract those words said earlier. She didn't want anyone to think that Egwene had been supporting Elaida. "I assume that Silviana's sentence has been dismissed?"

"nɑt kəmplitli, mʌðɝ," maɪdɑni sɛd. "ʃi ɪz biɪŋ hɛld əz ðə hɔl dɪsaɪdz wʌt tə də tə hɝ.

"Not completely, Mother," Meidani said. "She is being held as the Hall decides what to do to her.

ʃi stɪl dɪfaɪd ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪn ə vɛɹi pʌblɪk weɪ, ən ðəɹ ɪz tɔk ə pɛnəns."

She still defied the Amyrlin in a very public way, and there is talk of penance."

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd. ɪt smɛld ʌv ə kɑmpɹəmaɪz; ɪleɪɾə hæd pɹɑbli mɛɾ ɪn kloʊz kɑnfɝəns wɪð ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ - huɛvɝ ðət wɑz, naʊ ðət ɡəlinə hæd vænɪʃt - hæʃɪŋ aʊt ðə dɪteɪlz.

Egwene frowned. It smelled of a compromise; Elaida had probably met in closed conference with the head of the Red Ajah - whoever that was, now that Galina had vanished - hashing out the details.

sɪlviænə wəd stɪl bi pʌnɪʃt, ɔlðoʊ nɑɾ əz stʃɹɔŋli, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə wəd səbmɪt tə ðə wɪl ə ðə hɔl. ɪɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑz ɑn ʃeɪki ɡɹaʊnd, bʌt ðət ʃi kəd stɪl meɪk dɪmænz. hɝ səpɔɹt wɑzn əz kəmplitli ɪɹoʊɾəd wɪðɪn əɹ oʊn ədʒɑ əz ɛɡwin hæd hoʊpt.

Silviana would still be punished, although not as strongly, but Elaida would submit to the will of the Hall. It indicated that Elaida was on shaky ground, but that she could still make demands. Her support wasn't as completely eroded within her own Ajah as Egwene had hoped.

stɪl, ðɪs wɑz ə fɔɹtʃənət tɝn ʌv ɪvɛns. sɪlviænə wəd lɪv, ən ɛɡwin - ɪɾ əpɪɹd - wəd bi əlaʊd tə ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ laɪf əz ə "nɑvəs." ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ dɪsplizd ɪnʌf wɪð ɪleɪɾə tə ɹɛpɹəmæn hɝ. ɡɪvən dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ taɪm, ɛɡwin wɑz kɑnfəɾənt ʃi kəd ɡɛt ðə wʊmən oʊvɝtɝn ən ðə taʊɝ ɹiunaɪɾɪd. bʌt dɛɹ ʃi spɛn ðət taɪm?

Still, this was a fortunate turn of events. Silviana would live, and Egwene - it appeared - would be allowed to return to her life as a "novice." The Sitters were displeased enough with Elaida to reprimand her. Given just a little more time, Egwene was confident she could get the woman overturned and the Tower reunited. But dare she spend that time?

ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə teɪbəl, wɛɹ ðə pɹɛʃəs bʊks leɪ hɪɾən fɹəm aɪz. ɪf ʃi steɪdʒd ə mæs əsɔlt ɑn ðə blæk ədʒɑ, wəd ðət pɹɪsɪpɪteɪɾ ə bæɾəl? wəd ʃi dɪsteɪbəlaɪz ðə taʊɝ ivən fɝðɝ? ən kəd ʃi ɹiəlɪstɪkli hoʊp tə stʃɹaɪk əɾ ɔl ə ðɛm laɪk ðæt? ʃi niɾəd taɪm tə kənsɪɾɝ ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. fəɹ naʊ, ðət mɛn steɪɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊɝ ən wɝkɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə. ænd, ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðət mɛn lɛɾɪŋ moʊst ə ðə blæk sɪstɝz ɹʌn fɹi.

She glanced at the table, where the precious books lay hidden from eyes. If she staged a mass assault on the Black Ajah, would that precipitate a battle? Would she destabilize the Tower even further? And could she realistically hope to strike at all of them like that? She needed time to consider the information. For now, that meant staying in the Tower and working against Elaida. And, unfortunately, that meant letting most of the Black sisters run free.

bʌt nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm. "maɪdɑni," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ wɑn jə tə ɹipɔɹt tə ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ mʌs teɪk ɑlviɛɝɪn ɪndə kæptɪvəɾi ən tɛst əɹ wɪð ði oʊθ ɹɑd. tɛl əm tə teɪk ɛni ɹizənəbəl ɹɪsk tə ətʃiv ɪt."

But not all of them. "Meidani," Egwene said. "I want you to report to the others. They must take Alviarin into captivity and test her with the Oath Rod. Tell them to take any reasonable risk to achieve it."

"ɑlviɛɝɪn, mʌðɝ?" maɪdɑni æskt. "waɪ hɝ?"

"Alviarin, Mother?" Meidani asked. "Why her?"

"ʃiz blæk," ɛɡwin sɛd, stʌmək tɝnɪŋ. "ænd nɪɹ ðə hɛɾ ə ðɛɹ ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən ɪn ðə taʊɝ. ðɪs wɑz ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən vɛɹɪn daɪd tə bɹɪŋ mi."

"She's Black," Egwene said, stomach turning. "And near the head of their organization in the Tower. This was the information Verin died to bring me."

maɪdɑni peɪld. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən, mʌðɝ?"

Meidani paled. "Are you certain, Mother?"

"aɪm kɑnfəɾənt ɪn vɛɹɪnz tʃɹʌstwɝðinəs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪt wəd stɪl bi ədvaɪzəbəl tə hæv ʌðɝz ɹimuv, ðən ɹipleɪs, ɑlviɛɝɪnz oʊðz ən æsk əɹ ɪf ʃiz blæk. ɛvɹi wʊmən ʃəd bi ɡɪvən ðət tʃæns tə pɹuv hɝsɛlf, noʊ mæɾɝ ði ɛvəɾəns. juv ði oʊθ ɹɑd, aɪ əsum?"

"I'm confident in Verin's trustworthiness," Egwene said. "But it would still be advisable to have others remove, then replace, Alviarin's oaths and ask her if she's Black. Every woman should be given that chance to prove herself, no matter the evidence. You have the Oath Rod, I assume?"

"jɛs," maɪdɑni sɛd. "wi niɾəd ɪt tə pɹuv nɪkoʊləz tʃɹʌstwɝðinəs; ði ʌðɝz wɑntəd tə bɹɪŋ səm æksɛptɪɾ ən nɑvəsɪz ɪn, əz ðeɪ kən ɹʌn mɛsədʒəz wɛɹ sɪstɝz kænɑt ɡoʊ."

"Yes," Meidani said. "We needed it to prove Nicola's trustworthiness; the others wanted to bring some Accepted and novices in, as they can run messages where sisters cannot go."

ɪt wɑz waɪz, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə dɪvɪʒənz əmʌŋ ði ədʒəz. "waɪ hɝ?"

It was wise, considering the divisions among the Ajahs. "Why her?"

"bɪkɔz ə haʊ ɔfən ʃi spiks tə ði ʌðɝz əbaʊt ju, mʌðɝ," maɪdɑni sɛd. "ɪts wɛl noʊn ðət ʃiz wʌn ə jəɹ ɡɹeɪɾəst ædvəkəts əmʌŋ ðə nɑvəsɪz."

"Because of how often she speaks to the others about you, Mother," Meidani said. "It's well known that she's one of your greatest advocates among the novices."

ɪt wɑz ɑd tə hɪɹ ðəɾ ʌv ə wʊmən u hæɾ ɪfɛktɪvli bɪtʃɹeɪd hɝ, bʌt ðə ɡɝl kʊdn ɹɪli bi bleɪm fəɹ ðæt, ɔl θɪŋz kənsɪɾɝd.

It was odd to hear that of a woman who had effectively betrayed her, but the girl couldn't really be blamed for that, all things considered.

"ðeɪ dɪdn lɛɾ əɹ swɛɹ ɔl θɹi oʊðz, ʌv kɔɹs," maɪdɑni sɛd. "ʃiz nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ʃi dɪd teɪk ði oʊθ əbaʊt laɪɪŋ ən pɹuv hɝsɛlf nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. ðeɪ ɹimuv ði oʊθ æftɝ."

"They didn't let her swear all three oaths, of course," Meidani said. "She's not Aes Sedai. But she did take the oath about lying and proved herself not a Darkfriend. They removed the oath after."

"æn ju, maɪdɑni?" ɛɡwin æskt. "hæv ðeɪ ɹimuv ðə fɔɹθ oʊθ fɹəm ju?"

"And you, Meidani?" Egwene asked. "Have they removed the fourth oath from you?"

ðə wʊmən smaɪld. "jɛs, mʌðɝ. θæŋk ju."

The woman smiled. "Yes, Mother. Thank you."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. "ɡoʊ, ðɛn. pæs ɑn maɪ mɛsədʒ. ɑlviɛɝɪn mʌs bi teɪkən." ʃi ɡlænst ət vɛɹɪnz bɑɾi. "aɪm əfɹeɪɾ əl əv tə æsk jə tə teɪk əɹ wɪð jə əz wɛl. ɪɾəl bi bɛɾɝ ɪf ʃi vænɪʃɪz, əz əpoʊz tə maɪ hævɪŋ tə ɪkspleɪn əɹ dɛθ ɪn maɪ ɹum."

Egwene nodded. "Go, then. Pass on my message. Alviarin must be taken." She glanced at Verin's body. "I'm afraid I'll have to ask you to take her with you as well. It will be better if she vanishes, as opposed to my having to explain her death in my room."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"juz ə ɡeɪtweɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "skɪm ɪf jə doʊnt noʊ ði ɛɹiə wɛl ɪnʌf."

"Use a gateway," Egwene said. "Skim if you don't know the area well enough."

maɪdɑni nɑɾəd, ðən ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs.

Meidani nodded, then Embraced the Source.

"wiv sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, fɝst," ɛɡwin sɛd θɔtfəli. "ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ wʌt; sʌmθɪŋ ðət ɹikwaɪɝz ə lɑɾ ə paʊɝ. pɝhæps wʌn ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd wivz wʌn teɪks ɪn ðə tɛs tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Weave something else, first," Egwene said thoughtfully. "It doesn't matter what; something that requires a lot of power. Perhaps one of the hundred weaves one takes in the test to become Aes Sedai."

maɪdɑni fɹaʊnd, bʌt dɪɾ əz æskt, wivɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ən paʊɝ-ɪntɛnsɪv.

Meidani frowned, but did as asked, weaving something very complicated and power-intensive.

sun æftɝ ʃi bɪɡæn, tʊɹeɪzi poʊkt əɹ hɛɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum səspɪʃəsli. ðə wiv blɑkt əɹ saɪɾ ə vɛɹɪnz feɪs, fɔɹtʃənətli, bʌt tʊɹeɪzi wɑzn foʊkəst ɑn ðə "slipɪŋ" bɹaʊn. ʃi foʊkəst ɑn ðə wiv, oʊpənɪŋ əɹ maʊθ.

Soon after she began, Turese poked her head into the room suspiciously. The weave blocked her sight of Verin's face, fortunately, but Turese wasn't focused on the "sleeping" Brown. She focused on the weave, opening her mouth.

"ʃi ɪz ʃoʊɪŋ mi səm ə ðə wivz əl nid tə noʊ ɪf aɪ teɪk ðə tɛs tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd kɝtli, kʌɾɪŋ ɔf tʊɹeɪziz wɝdz. "ɪz ðət fɔɹbɪɾən?"

"She is showing me some of the weaves I will need to know if I take the test to become Aes Sedai," Egwene said curtly, cutting off Turese's words. "Is that forbidden?"

tʊɹeɪzi ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɝ, bʌt pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌɾ ən wɪθdʒɹu.

Turese glared at her, but pulled the door shut and withdrew.

"ðæt wɑz tə pɹɪvɛn əɹ fɹəm poʊkɪŋ ɪn ən siɪŋ ðə wivz fəɹ ɡeɪtweɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"That was to prevent her from poking in and seeing the weaves for gateways," Egwene said.

"kwɪkli naʊ. teɪk ðə bɑɾi. wən tʊɹeɪzi lʊks ɪn əɡɛn, əl tɛl əɹ ðə tʃɹuθ - ðət jə ən vɛɹɪn lɛf θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ."

"Quickly now. Take the body. When Turese looks in again, I will tell her the truth - that you and Verin left through a gateway."

maɪdɑni ɡlænst ət vɛɹɪnz kɔɹps. "bʌt wʌt ʃəd wi də wɪð ðə bɑɾi?"

Meidani glanced at Verin's corpse. "But what should we do with the body?"

"wʌtɛvɝ simz əpɹoʊpɹiət," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɡɹoʊɪŋ tɛsti. "aɪl liv ðət tə ju. aɪ doʊn əv ðə taɪm tə dil wɪð ɪt naʊ. ən teɪk ðət kʌp wɪð ju; ðə ti ɪz pɔɪzənd. dɪspoʊz ʌv ɪt kɛɹfəli."

"Whatever seems appropriate," Egwene said, growing testy. "I'll leave that to you. I don't have the time to deal with it now. And take that cup with you; the tea is poisoned. Dispose of it carefully."

ɛɡwin ɡlænst əɾ əɹ flɪkɝɪŋ kændəl; ɪt wɑz bɝnd nɪɹli ɔl ðə weɪ daʊn tə ðə teɪbəl ɪtsɛlf.

Egwene glanced at her flickering candle; it was burned nearly all the way down to the table itself.

tə ðə saɪd, maɪdɑni saɪd sɔfli, ðən kɹieɪɾəd ə ɡeɪtweɪ. wivz ʌv ɛɹ muvd vɛɹɪnz bɑɾi ɪn θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ, ən ɛɡwin wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ wɪð ə pæŋ ə ɹəɡɹɛt. ðə wʊmən hæd dɪzɝv bɛɾɝ. sʌmdeɪ, ɪt wəd bi noʊn wʌt ʃi hæd sʌfɝɾ ən wʌt ʃi hæɾ əkɑmplɪʃt. bʌt nɑt fəɹ ə taɪm jɛt.

To the side, Meidani sighed softly, then created a gateway. Weaves of Air moved Verin's body in through the opening, and Egwene watched her go with a pang of regret. The woman had deserved better. Someday, it would be known what she had suffered and what she had accomplished. But not for a time yet.

wʌns maɪdɑni wɑz ɡɔn wɪð ðə kɔɹps ən ðə ti, ɛɡwin lɪɾ ənʌðɝ kændəl, ðən leɪ daʊn ɑn əɹ bɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə θɪŋk ə ðə bɑɾi ðət hæɾ ɑkjəpaɪɾ ɪt pɹiviəsli. ʃi ɹɪlæks hɝsɛlf, θɪŋkɪŋ ə sɪuən. ðə wʊmən wəd bi gɑnə slip sun. ʃi niɾəd tə bi wɔɹn əbaʊt ʃɛɹiəm ən ði ʌðɝz.

Once Meidani was gone with the corpse and the tea, Egwene lit another candle, then lay down on her bed, trying not to think of the body that had occupied it previously. She relaxed herself, thinking of Siuan. The woman would be going to sleep soon. She needed to be warned about Sheriam and the others.

ɛɡwin oʊpən əɹ aɪz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ʃi wɑz ɪn əɹ ɹum, əɹ ət lis ðə dʒɹim vɝʒən ʌv ɪt. ðə bɛd wɑz meɪd, ðə dɔɹ kloʊzd. ʃi tʃeɪnʒd əɹ dʒɹɛs tə ðəɾ ʌv ə steɪtli ɡɹin ɡaʊn fɪɾɪŋ ən æmɪɝlɪn, ðən muv hɝsɛlf tə ðə taʊɝz spɹɪŋ ɡɑɹɾən. sɪuən wɑzn ðəɹ jɛt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli stɪl ə lɪɾəl ɝli fəɹ ðɛɹ miɾɪŋ.

Egwene opened her eyes in Tel'aran'rhiod. She was in her room, or at least the dream version of it. The bed was made, the door closed. She changed her dress to that of a stately green gown fitting an Amyrlin, then moved herself to the Tower's Spring Garden. Siuan wasn't there yet, but it was probably still a little early for their meeting.

hɪɹ, ət list, wʌn kəd si nʌn ə ðə fɪlθ ðət paɪld ʌp ɪn ðə sɪɾi əɹ ðə kɝʌpʃən ðət wɝkt ət ðə ɹuts ʌv ədʒɑ junəɾi. ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾənɝz muv laɪk nætʃɹəl fɔɹsɪz, plæntɪŋ, kʌltɪveɪɾɪŋ, ən hɑɹvəstɪŋ əz æmɪɝlənz ɹoʊz ən fɛl. ðə spɹɪŋ ɡɑɹɾən wɑz smɔlɝ ðən moʊst ə ði ʌðɝ taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾənz; ɪt wɑz ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ plɑɾ ə læn pɹɛs bɪtwin tu wɔlz. pɝhæps ɪn ənʌðɝ sɪɾi, ðɪs plɑt wʊɾə bɪn juz fəɹ stɔɹədʒ əɹ sɪmpli fɪld ɪn wɪð stoʊn. bʌɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, boʊθ ɑpʃənz wʊɾə bɪn ənsaɪtli.

Here, at least, one could see none of the filth that piled up in the city or the corruption that worked at the roots of Ajah unity. The Tower gardeners moved like natural forces, planting, cultivating, and harvesting as Amyrlins rose and fell. The Spring Garden was smaller than most of the other Tower gardens; it was a triangular plot of land pressed between two walls. Perhaps in another city, this plot would have been used for storage or simply filled in with stone. But in the White Tower, both options would have been unsightly.

ðə səluʃən wɑz ə smɔl ɡɑɹɾən fʊl ə plæns ðət θɹaɪvd ɪn ðə ʃeɪd. haɪdʒɹeɪnɡis ɹæn ʌp ðə wɔlz ən sɝdʒd ɝaʊn plæntɝz. bliɾɪŋ hɑɹts sæɾ ɪn ɹoʊz, wɪð ðɛɹ taɪni pɪŋk blɑsəmz dʒɹupɪŋ fɹəm dɛləkət θɹi-pɹɔŋ kɑmpaʊn livz. flaʊɝɪŋ bɹɪslbaʊz, wɪð ðɛɹ θɪn, fɪŋɡɝlaɪk livz, ən ʌðɝ smɔl ʃeɪd tʃɹiz ɹæn əlɔŋ ði ɪnsaɪdz ə ðə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ wɔlz, miɾɪŋ ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl pɔɪnt.

The solution was a small garden full of plants that thrived in the shade. Hydrangeas ran up the walls and surged around planters. Bleeding hearts sat in rows, with their tiny pink blossoms drooping from delicate three-pronged compound leaves. Flowering bristleboughs, with their thin, fingerlike leaves, and other small shade trees ran along the insides of the triangular walls, meeting in a single point.

wɔkɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ðə laɪnz ə tʃɹiz əz ʃi weɪɾəd, ɛɡwin θɔɾ ə ʃɛɹiəm biɪŋ blæk.

Walking up and down the lines of trees as she waited, Egwene thought of Sheriam being Black.

haʊ mɛni θɪŋz hæd ðə wʊmən hæɾ ə hæn ɪn? ʃid bɪn mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz fəɹ jɪɹz dʊɹɪŋ sɪuənz tɛnjɝ əz æmɪɝlɪn. hæd ʃi juzd əɹ pəzɪʃən tə bʊli, pɝhæps tə tɝn, ʌðɝ sɪstɝz? hæd ʃi bɪn bɪhaɪn ði ətæk ə ðə ɡɹeɪ mæn soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ?

How many things had the woman had a hand in? She'd been Mistress of Novices for years during Siuan's tenure as Amyrlin. Had she used her position to bully, perhaps to turn, other sisters? Had she been behind the attack of the Gray Man so long ago?

ʃɛɹiəm hæd bɪn pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹup ðət hil mæt. ʃʊɹli ʃi cʊɾə dʌn nʌθɪŋ məlɪʃəs waɪl ɪn ə sɝkəl wɪð soʊ mɛni ʌðɝ wɪmən - bʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪnvɑlvɪŋ ðə wʊmən wɑz sʌspɛkt. ðət wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ! ʃɛɹiəm hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə sɑlədɑɹ bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwinz ɹaɪz tə paʊɝ. wʌt hæd ʃɛɹiəm dʌn, haʊ mʌtʃ mənɪpjəleɪʃən hæd ʃi ɪɡzɝɾɪd ðɛn, haʊ mʌtʃ hæd ʃi bɪtʃɹeɪd tə ðə ʃædoʊ?

Sheriam had been part of the group that Healed Mat. Surely she could have done nothing malicious while in a circle with so many other women - but anything involving the woman was suspect. That was so much! Sheriam had been one of those in charge of Salidar before Egwene's rise to power. What had Sheriam done, how much manipulation had she exerted then, how much had she betrayed to the Shadow?

hæd ʃi bɪn əwɛɹ əhɛɾ ə taɪm ʌv ɪleɪɾəz plænz tə dɪpoʊz sɪuən? ɡəlinə ən ɑlviɛɝɪn wɝ blæk, ən ðeɪ hæd bɪn tu ʌv ðə meɪn ɪnstəɡeɪɾɝz, soʊ ɪt sim laɪkli ʌðɝ blæks hæd bɪn wɔɹnd. wɝ ði ɛksəɾəs ə hæf ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, ən ðə sʌbsəkwənt weɪɾɪŋ ən dəbeɪɾɪŋ ɔl pɑɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz plæn? wʌɾ ʌv ɛɡwinz oʊn ɹaɪz tə paʊɝ? haʊ mɛni ʌv ðə ʃædoʊz stʃɹɪŋz dɪd ʃi dæns ɑn wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ ɪt?

Had she been aware ahead of time of Elaida's plans to depose Siuan? Galina and Alviarin were Black, and they had been two of the main instigators, so it seemed likely other Blacks had been warned. Were the exodus of half of the Tower, the gathering in Salidar, and the subsequent waiting and debating all part of the Dark One's plan? What of Egwene's own rise to power? How many of the Shadow's strings did she dance on without knowing it?

ðɪs ɪz ən ɛksɝsaɪz ɪn fjutɪləɾi, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf fɝmli. doʊnt ɡoʊ daʊn ðət pæθ. ivən wɪθaʊt vɛɹɪnz bʊks, ɛɡwin hæd səspɛktəd ðət ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə taʊɝ wɑz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz wɝk. ʌv kɔɹs i wəd bi pliz ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd splɪɾ ɪn tu, ɹæðɝ ðən junəfaɪɪŋ bɪhaɪnd wʌn liɾɝ.

This is an exercise in futility, she told herself firmly. Don't go down that path. Even without Verin's books, Egwene had suspected that the breaking of the Tower was the Dark One's work. Of course he would be pleased that the Aes Sedai had split in two, rather than unifying behind one leader.

ɪt wɑz dʒʌs mɔɹ . . . pɝsənəl naʊ. ɛɡwin fɛl dɝɾid, ʃi fɛl dupt. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi fɛl hɝsɛlf tə bi ðə kʌntʃɹi ɡɝl mɛni θɔɾ əɹ tə bi. ɪf ɪleɪɾə hæd bɪn ə pɔn fəɹ ðə blæks, ðən soʊ hæd ʃi. laɪt! haʊ ðə dɑɹk wʌn mʌst əv læf tə si tu ɹaɪvəl æmɪɝlənz, itʃ wɪð wʌn ə hɪz lɔɪəl mɪnjənz əɾ əɹ saɪd, pɪɾɪŋ əm əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ.

It was just more . . . personal now. Egwene felt dirtied, she felt duped. For a moment, she felt herself to be the country girl many thought her to be. If Elaida had been a pawn for the Blacks, then so had she. Light! How the Dark One must have laughed to see two rival Amyrlins, each with one of his loyal minions at her side, pitting them against one another.

aɪ kæn bi sɝɾən ɪɡzækli wʌɾ i wɑns əɹ waɪ hi wɑns ɪt, vɛɹɪn hæd sɛd. ivən æftɝ jɪɹz ə stʌɾi, aɪ kæn bi sɝɾən. . . . hu nu wɛðɝ ðə dɑɹk wʌn læft?

I can't be certain exactly what he wants or why he wants it, Verin had said. Even after years of study, I can't be certain. . . . Who knew whether the Dark One laughed?

ʃi ʃɪvɝd. wʌtɛvɝ ɪz plæn, ʃi wəd faɪt hɪm. ɹɪzɪs hɪm. spɪɾ ɪn ɪz aɪ, ivən ɪf i wʌn, dʒʌst əz ði il sɛd.

She shivered. Whatever his plan, she would fight him. Resist him. Spit in his eye, even if he won, just as the Aiel said.

"wɛl, ðæts ə saɪt," sɪuənz vɔɪs sɛd.

"Well, that's a sight," Siuan's voice said.

ɛɡwin spʌn, ɹilaɪzɪŋ wɪð ʃəɡɹɪn ðət ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɔɹ ðə dʒɹɛs ə ði æmɪɝlɪn, bʌɾ ə fʊl suɾ ʌv ɑɹmɝ laɪk ə soʊlʒɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə bæɾəl. ɪn əɹ hænd, ʃi kæɹiɾ ə pɛɹ ʌv il spɪɹz.

Egwene spun, realizing with chagrin that she no longer wore the dress of the Amyrlin, but a full suit of armor like a soldier riding to battle. In her hand, she carried a pair of Aiel spears.

ʃi bænɪʃt ɑɹmɝ ən spɪɹz wɪð ə θɔt, ɹɪzumɪŋ ðə dʒɹɛs. "sɪuən," ʃi sɛd kɝtli. "ju meɪ wɑnə sʌmən jɝsɛlf ə tʃɛɹ. sʌmθɪŋ əz hæpənd."

She banished armor and spears with a thought, resuming the dress. "Siuan," she said curtly. "You may want to summon yourself a chair. Something has happened."

sɪuən fɹaʊnd. "wʌt?"

Siuan frowned. "What?"

"fɝst ɔf, ʃɛɹiəm ən mɔɹiə ɑɹ blæk ədʒɑ."

"First off, Sheriam and Moria are Black Ajah."

"wʌt?" sɪuən sɛd, ʃɑkt. "wʌt nɑnsɛns ɪz ðɪs?" ʃi fɹoʊz. "mʌðɝ," ʃi æɾəd bɪleɪɾədli.

"What?" Siuan said, shocked. "What nonsense is this?" She froze. "Mother," she added belatedly.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt nɑnsɛns," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðə tʃɹuθ, aɪm əfɹeɪd. ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝz, bʌɾ əl əv tə ɡɪv jə ðɛɹ neɪmz leɪɾɝ. wi kæn jɛt teɪk əm ɪndə kʌstəɾi. aɪ nid taɪm tə plæn ən θɪŋk, ən ivnɪŋ pɝhæps. wɪl stʃɹaɪk sun. bʌɾ əntɪl wi du, aɪ wɑnt ʃɛɹiəm ən mɔɹiə wɑtʃt. doʊn bi əloʊn ɝaʊn ðɛm."

"It is not nonsense," Egwene said. "The truth, I'm afraid. There are others, but I will have to give you their names later. We can't yet take them into custody. I need time to plan and think, an evening perhaps. We will strike soon. But until we do, I want Sheriam and Moria watched. Don't be alone around them."

sɪuən ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. "haʊ sɝɾən ɑɹ jə əbaʊt ðɪs, ɛɡwin?"

Siuan shook her head in disbelief. "How certain are you about this, Egwene?"

"sɝɾən ɪnʌf," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wɑtʃ ðɛm, sɪuən, ən bi θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv wʌt tə du. əl wɑnə hɪɹ jəɹ sədʒɛstʃənz. wɪl niɾ ə weɪ tə teɪk əm kwaɪətli, ðən pɹuv tə ðə hɔl ðət wʌt wiv dʌn ɪz dʒʌstəfaɪd."

"Certain enough," Egwene said. "Watch them, Siuan, and be thinking of what to do. I'll want to hear your suggestions. We'll need a way to take them quietly, then prove to the Hall that what we've done is justified."

"ðɪs kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs." sɪuən ɹʌbd əɹ tʃɪn. "aɪ hoʊp jə noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ duɪŋ, mʌðɝ." ʃi ɛmfəsaɪz ðə læst wɝd.

"This could be dangerous." Siuan rubbed her chin. "I hope you know what you are doing, Mother." She emphasized the last word.

"ɪf aɪ ɛɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ðɛn ɪɾəl bi ɑn maɪ hɛd. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪ du. əz aɪ sɛd, mʌtʃ əz tʃeɪnʒd."

"If I err," Egwene said, "then it will be on my head. But I don't think that I do. As I said, much has changed."

sɪuən baʊɾ əɹ hɛd. "ɑɹ jə stɪl kæptɪv?"

Siuan bowed her head. "Are you still captive?"

"nɑɾ ɪɡzækli. ɪleɪɾə hæz - " ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ.

"Not exactly. Elaida has - " Egwene hesitated, frowning to herself. Something was wrong.

"ɛɡwin?" sɪuən æskt, æŋkʃəs.

"Egwene?" Siuan asked, anxious.

"aɪ. . . ." ɛɡwin bɪɡæn, ðən ʃʌɾɝəd. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz pʊlɪŋ ɑn əɹ maɪnd, klaʊɾɪŋ ɪt.

"I. . . ." Egwene began, then shuddered. Something was pulling on her mind, clouding it.

sʌmθɪŋ wɑz . . .

Something was . . .

pʊlɪŋ əɹ bæk. tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd wɪŋkt əweɪ ən ɛɡwin oʊpən əɹ aɪz bæk ɪn əɹ ɹum, ən æŋkʃəs nɪkoʊlə ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm. "mʌðɝ," ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ. "mʌðɝ!"

Pulling her back. Tel'aran'rhiod winked away and Egwene opened her eyes back in her room, an anxious Nicola shaking her arm. "Mother," she was saying. "Mother!"

ðə ɡɝl hæɾ ə blʌɾi ɡæʃ ɑn əɹ tʃik. ɛɡwin sæɾ ʌp ʃɑɹpli, ən ət ðət moʊmən ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ ʃʊk əz ɪf fɹəm ən ɪksploʊʒən. nɪkoʊlə ɡɹæbd əɹ ɑɹm, jɛlpɪŋ ɪn fɹaɪt.

The girl had a bloody gash on her cheek. Egwene sat up sharply, and at that moment the entire Tower shook as if from an explosion. Nicola grabbed her arm, yelping in fright.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?" ɛɡwin dɪmændəd.

"What is going on?" Egwene demanded.

"ʃæɾoʊzpɔn!" nɪkoʊlə kɹaɪd. "ɪn ði ɛɹ, sɝpəns ðət θɹoʊ fleɪm ən wivz ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ! ðəɹ dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ʌs! oʊ, mʌðɝ. ɪts tɑɹmən ɡdən!"

"Shadowspawn!" Nicola cried. "In the air, serpents that throw flame and weaves of the One Power! They're destroying us! Oh, Mother. It's Tarmon Gai'don!"

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə moʊmən ə pɹaɪməl, nɪɹli ʌnkəntʃɹoʊləbəl pænɪk. tɑɹmən ɡdən! ðə læs bæɾəl!

Egwene felt a moment of primal, nearly uncontrollable panic. Tarmon Gai'don! The Last Battle!

ʃi hɝd skɹimz ɪn ðə dɪstəns, fɑloʊd baɪ ðə ʃaʊts ə soʊlʒɝz əɹ wɔɹɾɝz. noʊ . . . noʊ, ʃi niɾəd tə foʊkəs! sɝpəns ɪn ði ɛɹ. sɝpəns ðət wildɪd ðə wʌn paʊɝ . . . əɹ wɪð ɹaɪɾɝz ðət wildɪd ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɛɡwin θɹu ɔf ðə blæŋkəɾ ən lɛp tə hɝ fit.

She heard screams in the distance, followed by the shouts of soldiers or Warders. No . . . no, she needed to focus! Serpents in the air. Serpents that wielded the One Power . . . or with riders that wielded the One Power. Egwene threw off the blanket and leaped to her feet.

ɪt wɑzn tɑɹmən ɡdən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɪɹli əz bæd. ðə sintʃæn hæd faɪnəli ətæk ðə waɪt taʊɝ, dʒʌst əz ɛɡwin hæd dʒɹimd.

It wasn't Tarmon Gai'don, but it was nearly as bad. The Seanchan had finally attacked the White Tower, just as Egwene had Dreamed.

ən ʃi kʊdn tʃænəl ɪnʌf paʊɝ tə laɪɾ ə kændəl, lɛɾ əloʊn faɪt bæk.

And she couldn't channel enough Power to light a candle, let alone fight back.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾi

CHAPTER 40

ðə taʊɝ ʃeɪks sɪuən əwoʊk wɪð ə stɑɹt. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz vɛɹi, vɛɹi ɹɔŋ. ʃi skɹæmbəld ɔf ə hɝ pælət. əz ʃi dɪd, ə dɑɹk fɪɡjɝ muv sʌɾənli ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt, mɛɾəl ɹæspɪŋ əɡɛns mɛɾəl. sɪuən fɹoʊz, ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs ɹiflɛksɪvli ən sʌmənɪŋ ə ɡloʊb ə laɪt.

The Tower Shakes Siuan awoke with a start. Something was wrong. Something was very, very wrong. She scrambled off of her pallet. As she did, a dark figure moved suddenly on the other side of the tent, metal rasping against metal. Siuan froze, embracing the Source reflexively and summoning a globe of light.

ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn stʊɾ əlɝt, hɛɹən-mɑɹk stil dʒɹɔn ən ɹɛɾi. hi wɔɹ oʊnli hɪz smɔlkloʊðz, ən ʃi hæd tə kip hɝsɛlf fɹəm stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪz mʌsəl bɑɾi, wɪtʃ wɑz ɪn fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ʃeɪp ðən ðəɾ ə moʊs mɛn hæf ɪz eɪdʒ. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" hi æsk tɛnsli.

Gareth Bryne stood alert, heron-marked steel drawn and ready. He wore only his smallclothes, and she had to keep herself from staring at his muscled body, which was in far better shape than that of most men half his age. "What is it?" he asked tensely.

"laɪt!" sɪuən sɛd. "ju slip wɪð jəɹ sɔɹd?"

"Light!" Siuan said. "You sleep with your sword?"

"ɔlweɪz."

"Always."

"ɛɡwin ɪz ɪn deɪnʒɝ."

"Egwene is in danger."

"wʌt kaɪndə deɪnʒɝ?"

"What kind of danger?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ʃi ədmɪɾəd. "wi wɝ miɾɪŋ ən ʃi vænɪʃt sʌɾənli. aɪ θɪŋk . . . aɪ θɪŋk ɪleɪɾə meɪ hæv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɛksəkjut hɝ. əɹ ət lis pʊl əɹ fɹəm əɹ sɛl ən . . . də sʌmθɪŋ tə hɝ."

"I don't know," she admitted. "We were meeting and she vanished suddenly. I think . . . I think Elaida may have decided to execute her. Or at least pull her from her cell and . . . do something to her."

bɹaɪn dɪdn æsk fəɹ dɪteɪlz. hi sɪmpli ʃiðd ɪz sɔɹd, ðən pɹəsiɾəd tə pʊɾ ɑn ə pɛɹ ə tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə ʃɝt. sɪuən stɪl wɔɹ əɹ naʊ-ɹɪŋkəl blu skɝɾ ən blaʊs - ɪt wɑz əɹ hæbət tə tʃeɪnʒ æftɝ əɹ miɾɪŋz wɪð ɛɡwin, wʌns bɹaɪn wɑz saʊn əslip.

Bryne didn't ask for details. He simply sheathed his sword, then proceeded to put on a pair of trousers and a shirt. Siuan still wore her now-wrinkled blue skirt and blouse - it was her habit to change after her meetings with Egwene, once Bryne was sound asleep.

ʃi fɛlt ən æŋzaɪəɾi ʃi kʊdn kwaɪt dɪfaɪn. waɪ wɑz ʃi soʊ ɑn ɛdʒ? ɪt wɑzn ənkɑmən fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə weɪk ə pɝsən waɪl ðeɪ wɝ dʒɹimɪŋ.

She felt an anxiety she couldn't quite define. Why was she so on edge? It wasn't uncommon for something to wake a person while they were dreaming.

bʌt moʊs pipəl wɝn ɛɡwin. ʃi wɑz ə mæstɝ ə ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz. ɪf sʌmθɪŋ hæɾ əweɪkən əɹ ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli, ʃi wʊɾə dɛlt wɪð ɪt, ðən ɹɪtɝn tə kɑm sɪuənz wɝiz. bʌt ʃi hædnt, dɪspaɪt sɪuənz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ wʌt hæd sim laɪk ən ɪtɝnəɾi.

But most people weren't Egwene. She was a master of the World of Dreams. If something had awakened her unexpectedly, she would have dealt with it, then returned to calm Siuan's worries. But she hadn't, despite Siuan's waiting for what had seemed like an eternity.

bɹaɪn stɛpt ʌp tə hɝ, naʊ wɛɹɪŋ ɪz stɪf ɡɹeɪ tʃɹaʊzɝz ən junəfɔɹm koʊt. hid bʌɾənd ʌp ɪz haɪ kɑlɝ, mɑɹkt wɪð θɹi stɑɹz ɑn ðə lɛf bɹɛst ən ɡoʊldən ɛpaʊləts ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝz.

Bryne stepped up to her, now wearing his stiff gray trousers and uniform coat. He'd buttoned up his high collar, marked with three stars on the left breast and golden epaulets on the shoulders.

ə fɹɛnzid vɔɪs kɔl fɹəm aʊtsaɪd. "dʒɛnɝəl bɹaɪn! maɪ lɔɹd dʒɛnɝəl!"

A frenzied voice called from outside. "General Bryne! My Lord General!"

bɹaɪn ɡlænst ət hɝ, ðən tɝn təwɔɹd ðə tɛn flæps. "kʌm!"

Bryne glanced at her, then turned toward the tent flaps. "Come!"

ə juθfəl soʊlʒɝ wɪð nit blæk hɛɹ pʊʃt ɪndə ðə tɛn ən ɡeɪv ə kwɪk səlut. hi dɪdn əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ kʌmɪŋ soʊ leɪt - bɹaɪnz mɛn nu ðət ðɛɹ dʒɛnɝəl tʃɹʌstɪɾ əm tə əweɪk ɪm ɪf ðəɹ wɑz nid. "maɪ lɔɹd," ðə mæn sɛd. "skaʊts ɹipɔɹt. sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə sɪɾi."

A youthful soldier with neat black hair pushed into the tent and gave a quick salute. He didn't apologize for coming so late - Bryne's men knew that their general trusted them to awake him if there was need. "My Lord," the man said. "Scout's report. Something is going on in the city."

" 'sʌmθɪŋ,' aɪdz?" bɹaɪn æskt.

" 'Something,' Tijds?" Bryne asked.

"ðə skaʊts ɑɹən sɝɾən, maɪ lɔɹd," ðə mæn sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. "wɪð ðə klaʊd kʌvɝ, ðə naɪɾ ɪz dɑɹk, ən ðə spaɪɡlæsəz ɑɹən mʌtʃ hɛlp. ðəɹ əv bɪn bɝsts ə laɪt nɪɹ ðə taʊɝ, laɪk ən ɪluməneɪɾɝz ʃoʊ. dɑɹk ʃædoʊz ɪn ði ɛɹ."

"The scouts aren't certain, my Lord," the man said with a grimace. "With the cloud cover, the night is dark, and the spyglasses aren't much help. There have been bursts of light near the Tower, like an Illuminator's show. Dark shadows in the air."

"ʃæɾoʊzpɔn?" bɹaɪn æskt, pʊʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. wɪð ðə ɡloʊb ə laɪt, sɪuən ən ðə soʊlʒɝ fɑloʊd. ðə mun wəd bi bɛɹli ə slɪvɝ, ən wɪð ðoʊz pɝpɛtʃuəl klaʊdz, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə si ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. ðə tɛns ə ði ɔfəsɝz wɝ slʌmbɝɪŋ bæŋks ə blæk ɑn blæk ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən ði oʊnli ɹɪli dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl laɪts wɝ ðə wɑtʃfaɪɝz ə ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə pælɪsɑɾ ɛntʃɹəns.

"Shadowspawn?" Bryne asked, pushing out of the tent. With the globe of light, Siuan and the soldier followed. The moon would be barely a sliver, and with those perpetual clouds, it was difficult to see anything at all. The tents of the officers were slumbering banks of black on black around them, and the only really distinguishable lights were the watchfires of the guards at the palisade entrance.

"ðeɪ kəd bi ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, maɪ lɔɹd," ðə soʊlʒɝ sɛd, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ æftɝ bɹaɪn. "stɔɹiz tɛl ə kɹitʃɝz ə ʃædoʊ ðət flaɪ ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ. bʌt ðə skaʊts ɑɹən sɝɾən wʌt ðəɹ siɪŋ. ðə flæʃɪz ə laɪɾ ɑɹ ðəɹ fəɹ ʃʊɹ, ðoʊ."

"They could be Shadowspawn, my Lord," the soldier said, trotting after Bryne. "Stories tell of creatures of Shadow that fly in such a way. But the scouts aren't certain what they're seeing. The flashes of light are there for sure, though."

bɹaɪn nɑɾəd, hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə wɑtʃfaɪɝz. "əlɝt ðə naɪt ɡɑɹd; aɪ wɑn əm ʌp ən ɑɹmɝd, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. sɛn ɹʌnɝz tə ðə sɪɾi fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz. ən bɹɪŋ mi mɔɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən!"

Bryne nodded, heading toward the watchfires. "Alert the night guard; I want them up and armored, just in case. Send runners to the city fortifications. And bring me more information!"

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd." ðə soʊlʒɝ səluɾəd ən ɹæn ɔf.

"Yes, my Lord." The soldier saluted and ran off.

bɹaɪn ɡlænst ət sɪuən, hɪz feɪs ɪluməneɪɾəd baɪ ðə ɡloʊb ə laɪt hʌvɝɪŋ əbʌv əɹ hænd.

Bryne glanced at Siuan, his face illuminated by the globe of light hovering above her hand.

"ʃæɾoʊzpɔn wʊdn dɛɹ ətæk ðə waɪt taʊɝ," hi sɛd. "nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ə səbstæntʃəl ɡɹaʊn əsɔlt weɪɾɪŋ, ən aɪ sɪnsɪɹli daʊt ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən tʃɹɑləks haɪɾɪŋ ɪn wʌt lɪɾəl kʌvɝ ðiz pleɪnz ɔfɝ. soʊ wʌɾ ɪn ðə bleɪzɪz ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?"

"Shadowspawn wouldn't dare attack the White Tower," he said. "Not without a substantial ground assault waiting, and I sincerely doubt that there are a hundred thousand Trollocs hiding in what little cover these plains offer. So what in the blazes is going on?"

"sintʃæn," sɪuən sɛd, ə pɪɾ ʌv aɪs fɔɹmɪŋ ɪn əɹ stʌmək. "fɪʃ ɡʌts, ɡɛɹɪθ! ɪts tə bi.

"Seanchan," Siuan said, a pit of ice forming in her stomach. "Fish guts, Gareth! It has to be.

ɛɡwin pɹɪdɪktɪɾ ɪt."

Egwene predicted it."

hi nɑɾəd. "jɛs. ðeɪ ɹaɪd ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, səm ə ðə ɹumɝz seɪ."

He nodded. "Yes. They ride Shadowspawn, some of the rumors say."

"flaɪɪŋ bists," sɪuən sɛd, "nɑt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. ɛɡwin sɛd ðət ðəɹ kɔld ɹeɪkən."

"Flying beasts," Siuan said, "not Shadowspawn. Egwene said that they're called raken."

hi aɪɾ əɹ daʊtfəli, bʌt sɛɾ oʊnli, "wʌt wəd meɪk ðə sintʃæn soʊ fulhɑɹɾi əz tə ətæk wɪθaʊɾ ə ɡɹaʊn əsɔlt ɪn tændəm?"

He eyed her doubtfully, but said only, "What would make the Seanchan so foolhardy as to attack without a ground assault in tandem?"

sɪuən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ʃiɾ ɔlweɪz əsum ðəɾ ə sintʃæn stʃɹaɪk ət ðə waɪt taʊɝ wəd min ə lɑɹdʒ-skeɪl ɪnveɪʒən, ən ɛɡwin hæd ɡɛs ðət ði ətæk wɑz stɪl mʌnθs ɔf. laɪt! ɪt lʊk laɪk ɛɡwin kəd bi ɹɔŋ.

Siuan shook her head. She'd always assumed that a Seanchan strike at the White Tower would mean a large-scale invasion, and Egwene had guessed that the attack was still months off. Light! It looked like Egwene could be wrong.

bɹaɪn tɝn təwɔɹɾ ɪz wɑtʃfaɪɝz, wɪtʃ wɝ bleɪzɪŋ haɪɝ ɪn ðə naɪt, tɔsɪŋ laɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə fɹʌn ə ðə pælɪsɑd. ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹɪŋ ʌv wʊd, ɔfəsɝz wɝ ɹaʊzɪŋ, kɔlɪŋ tə neɪbɝɪŋ tɛns.

Bryne turned toward his watchfires, which were blazing higher in the night, tossing light across the front of the palisade. Inside the ring of wood, officers were rousing, calling to neighboring tents.

læmps ən læntɝnz wɪŋkt ɑn.

Lamps and lanterns winked on.

"wɛl," ɡɛɹɪθ sɛd, "soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ətæk tɑɹ vəlɑn, ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊ pɹɑbləm ʌv aʊɝz. wi dʒʌs nid tə - "

"Well," Gareth said, "so long as they attack Tar Valon, they are no problem of ours. We just need to - "

"aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ əɹ aʊt," sɪuən sɛd sʌɾənli, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ hɝsɛlf.

"I'm getting her out," Siuan said suddenly, surprising herself.

bɹaɪn spʌn təwɔɹd sɪuən, ɪndə ðə laɪɾ ə hɝ ɡloʊb. hɪz tʃɪn wɑz ʃæɾoʊd baɪ ivnɪŋ stʌbəl.

Bryne spun toward Siuan, into the light of her globe. His chin was shadowed by evening stubble.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"ɛɡwin," sɪuən sɛd. "wi nid tə ɡoʊ ɪn fəɹ hɝ. ðɪs wɪl pɹəvaɪɾ ə pɝfək dɪstʃɹækʃən, ɡɛɹɪθ!

"Egwene," Siuan said. "We need to go in for her. This will provide a perfect distraction, Gareth!

wi kən ɡoʊ ɪn ən ɡɹæb əɹ bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɪz ðə waɪzɝ."

We can go in and grab her before anyone is the wiser."

hi aɪd hɝ.

He eyed her.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"ju ɡeɪv jəɹ wɝd nɑt tə ɹɛskju hɝ, sɪuən." laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt fɛl naɪs tə hɪɹ ɪm juz əɹ neɪm!

"You gave your word not to rescue her, Siuan." Light, but it felt nice to hear him use her name!

foʊkəs! ʃi skoʊldəd hɝsɛlf. "ðæt dʌzn mæɾɝ naʊ. ʃiz ɪn deɪnʒɝ ən nidz hɛlp."

Focus! she scolded herself. "That doesn't matter now. She's in danger and needs help."

"ʃi dʌznt wɑn hɛlp," bɹaɪn sɛd stɝnli. "wi nid tə meɪk sɝɾən əɹ oʊn fɔɹs ɪz seɪf. ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz kɑnfəɾənt ðət ʃi kən kɛɹ fəɹ hɝsɛlf."

"She doesn't want help," Bryne said sternly. "We need to make certain our own force is safe. The Amyrlin is confident that she can care for herself."

"aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kəd kɛɹ fəɹ maɪsɛlf tu," sɪuən sɛd. "æn lʊk wɛɹ ɪt ɡɑt mi." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɪstən spaɪɹ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ʃi kəd dʒʌs feɪnli si ə bɝst ə laɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə spaɪɹ, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ɪt bɹifli. "wɛn ɛɡwin spiks ə ðə sintʃæn, ʃi ɔlweɪz ʃɪvɝz. vɛɹi lɪɾəl əpsɛts əɹ - nɑt ðə fɔɹseɪkən, nɑt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɡɛɹɪθ, jə doʊnt noʊ wʌt ðə sintʃæn də tə wɪmən u kən tʃænəl." ʃi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. "wi nid tə ɡoʊ fəɹ hɝ."

"I thought I could care for myself too," Siuan said. "And look where it got me." She shook her head, glancing toward the distant spire of Tar Valon. She could just faintly see a burst of light along the spire, illuminating it briefly. "When Egwene speaks of the Seanchan, she always shivers. Very little upsets her - not the Forsaken, not the Dragon Reborn. Gareth, you don't know what the Seanchan do to women who can channel." She met his eyes. "We need to go for her."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt bi ə pɑɹɾi tə ðɪs," hi sɛd stʌbɝnli.

"I will not be a party to this," he said stubbornly.

"faɪn," sɪuən spæt. ful mæn! "ɡoʊ teɪk kɛɹ ə jəɹ mɛn. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ sʌmwʌn u wɪl hɛlp mi." ʃi stɔkt əweɪ, hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə tɛn dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə pælɪsɑd.

"Fine," Siuan spat. Fool man! "Go take care of your men. I think I know someone who will help me." She stalked away, heading toward a tent just inside the palisade.

ɛɡwin stɛɾid hɝsɛlf əɡɛns ðə wɔl ə ðə hɔlweɪ əz ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ ʃʊk əɡɛn. ðə vɛɹi stoʊnz kwɪvɝd. fleɪks ə mɔɹɾɝ kɹʌmbəl daʊn fɹəm ðə silɪŋ, ən ə lus taɪl fɛl fɹəm ðə wɔl ən ʃæɾɝd ɪndə ə dʌzən ʃɑɹdz ɑn ðə flɔɹ. nɪkoʊlə skɹimd, ən klʌtʃt əɾ ɛɡwin.

Egwene steadied herself against the wall of the hallway as the entire Tower shook again. The very stones quivered. Flakes of mortar crumbled down from the ceiling, and a loose tile fell from the wall and shattered into a dozen shards on the floor. Nicola screamed, and clutched at Egwene.

"ðə dɑɹk wʌn!" nɪkoʊlə weɪld. "ðə læs bæɾəl! ɪts kʌm!"

"The Dark One!" Nicola wailed. "The Last Battle! It's come!"

"nɪkoʊlə!" ɛɡwin snæpt, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ʌp. "kəntʃɹoʊl jɝsɛlf. ðɪs ɪzən ðə læs bæɾəl. ɪts ðə sintʃæn."

"Nicola!" Egwene snapped, straightening up. "Control yourself. This isn't the Last Battle. It's the Seanchan."

"sintʃæn?" nɪkoʊlə sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌst ə ɹumɝ!"

"Seanchan?" Nicola said. "But I thought they were just a rumor!"

ful ɡɝl, ɛɡwin θɔt, hɝiɪŋ daʊn ə saɪd hɔlweɪ. nɪkoʊlə skʌɾəld æftɝ hɝ, kæɹiɪŋ əɹ læmp. ɛɡwinz mɛmɹi sɝvd əɹ kɝɛkli, ən ðə nɛks hɔlweɪ wɑz ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə taʊɝ, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə wɪndoʊ tə ði aʊtsaɪd. ʃi weɪv nɪkoʊlə tə ðə saɪd, ðən ɹɪskt ə ɡlæns aʊɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs.

Fool girl, Egwene thought, hurrying down a side hallway. Nicola scuttled after her, carrying her lamp. Egwene's memory served her correctly, and the next hallway was at the edge of the Tower, giving her a window to the outside. She waved Nicola to the side, then risked a glance out into the darkness.

ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, dɑɹk, wɪŋ fɔɹmz flæpt ɪn ðə skaɪ. ðoʊz wɝ tu bɪɡ tə bi ɹeɪkən. tɔɹeɪkən, ðɛn. ðeɪ swupt, wivz spɪnɪŋ ɝaʊn mɛni ʌv ðɛm, ɡloʊɪŋ ən vaɪbɹən tə ɛɡwinz aɪz.

Sure enough, dark, winged forms flapped in the sky. Those were too big to be raken. To'raken, then. They swooped, weaves spinning around many of them, glowing and vibrant to Egwene's eyes.

blæsts ə faɪɝ spɹæŋ ɪndə ɛɡzɪstəns, laɪɾɪŋ pɛɹz ʌv wɪmən ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə bæks ə ðə tɔɹeɪkən.

Blasts of fire sprang into existence, lighting pairs of women riding on the backs of the to'raken.

deɪmeɪn ən sʌldəm.

Damane and sul'dam.

pɔɹʃənz ə ðə taʊɝz wɪŋz bɪloʊ wɝ əlaɪt wɪð fleɪmz, ən tə hɝ hɔɹɝ, ɛɡwin sɔ sɛvɹəl ɡeɪpɪŋ hoʊlz dɝɛkli ɪn ðə saɪdz ə ðə taʊɝ. tɔɹeɪkən klʌtʃt ðə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, klaɪmɪŋ ʌp laɪk bæts klɪŋɪŋ tə ə wɔl, ənloʊɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝz ən deɪmeɪn ɪndə ðə bɪldɪŋ. əz ɛɡwin wɑtʃt, ə tɔɹeɪkən lɛp fɹi ʌv ðə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə haɪɾ əlaʊɪŋ ɪt tə fɔɹɡoʊ ɪts nɔɹməl ɹʌnɪŋ stɑɹt. ðə kɹitʃɝ wɑzn əz ɡɹeɪsfəl əz wʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ ɹeɪkən, bʌɾ ɪts hænlɝ dɪɾ ə mæstɝfəl dʒɑb ə dɝɛktɪŋ ɪt bæk ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ðə kɹitʃɝ flu ɹaɪt baɪ ɛɡwinz wɪndoʊ, ðə wɪn ʌv ɪts pæsɪŋ bloʊɪŋ bæk əɹ hɛɹ. ɛɡwin feɪnli hɝd skɹimɪŋ əz ðə tɔɹeɪkən swɛpt pæst.

Portions of the Tower's wings below were alight with flames, and to her horror, Egwene saw several gaping holes directly in the sides of the Tower. To'raken clutched the side of the Tower, climbing up like bats clinging to a wall, unloading soldiers and damane into the building. As Egwene watched, a to'raken leapt free of the side of the Tower, the height allowing it to forgo its normal running start. The creature wasn't as graceful as one of the smaller raken, but its handler did a masterful job of directing it back into the air. The creature flew right by Egwene's window, the wind of its passing blowing back her hair. Egwene faintly heard screaming as the to'raken swept past.

tɛɹəfaɪd skɹimɪŋ.

Terrified screaming.

ɪt wɑzn ə fʊl-skeɪl ətæk - ɪt wɑz ə ɹeɪd! ə ɹeɪd tə kæptʃɝ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn! ɛɡwin pʊl tə ðə saɪɾ əz ə blæst ə faɪɝ ʃɑt baɪ ðə wɪndoʊ ən hɪt ðə wɔl ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ. ʃi kəd hɪɹ ɹɑk kɹʌmbəl, ən ðə taʊɝ ʃʊk vaɪələnli. dʌst ən smoʊk ɪksploʊɾəd daʊn ə saɪd pæsədʒ ɔf ðə hɔlweɪ.

It wasn't a full-scale attack - it was a raid! A raid to capture marath'damane! Egwene pulled to the side as a blast of fire shot by the window and hit the wall a short distance away. She could hear rock crumble, and the Tower shook violently. Dust and smoke exploded down a side passage off the hallway.

soʊlʒɝz wəd sun fɑloʊ. soʊlʒɝz ən sʌldəm. wɪð ðoʊz liʃɪz. ɛɡwin ʃʌɾɝəd, ɹæpɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf. ðə kul, simləs mɛɾəl. ðə nɔziə, ðə dɛɡɹədeɪʃən, ðə pænɪk, dɪspɛɹ, ən - ʃeɪmfəli - ɡɪlt ət nɑt sɝvɪŋ əɹ mɪstʃɹəs tə ðə bɛst ə hɝ əbɪləɾiz. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə hɔntəd lʊk ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ʃi wɑz bɹoʊkən. moʊst ʌv ɔl, ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ oʊn tɛɹɝ.

Soldiers would soon follow. Soldiers and sul'dam. With those leashes. Egwene shuddered, wrapping her arms around herself. The cool, seamless metal. The nausea, the degradation, the panic, despair, and - shamefully - guilt at not serving her mistress to the best of her abilities. She remembered the haunted look of an Aes Sedai as she was broken. Most of all, she remembered her own terror.

ðə tɛɹɝ ə ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ʃi wəd bi laɪk ði ʌðɝz, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. dʒʌst ənʌðɝ sleɪv, hæpi tə sɝv.

The terror of realizing that she would be like the others, eventually. Just another slave, happy to serve.

ðə taʊɝ ʃʊk. faɪɝ flæʃt ɪn ðə dɪstən hɔlweɪz əkʌmpənid baɪ ʃaʊts ən weɪlz ə dɪspɛɹ. ʃi kəd smɛl smoʊk. oʊ, laɪt! kəd ðɪs ɹɪli bi? ʃi wʊdnt ɡoʊ bæk. ʃi wʊdn lɛɾ əm liʃ əɹ əɡɛn. ʃi hæd tə ɹʌn! ʃi hæd tə haɪd, fli, ɪskeɪp . . .

The Tower shook. Fire flashed in the distant hallways accompanied by shouts and wails of despair. She could smell smoke. Oh, Light! Could this really be? She wouldn't go back. She wouldn't let them leash her again. She had to run! She had to hide, flee, escape . . .

noʊ!

No!

ʃi pʊʃt hɝsɛlf əpɹaɪt.

She pushed herself upright.

noʊ, ʃi wəd nɑt fli. ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn.

No, she would not flee. She was Amyrlin.

nɪkoʊlə hʌɾəld bɪsaɪd ðə wɔl, wɪmpɝɪŋ. "ðeɪɹ kʌmɪŋ fəɹ ʌs," ðə ɡɝl wɪspɝd. "oʊ laɪt, ðəɹ kʌmɪŋ!"

Nicola huddled beside the wall, whimpering. "They're coming for us," the girl whispered. "Oh Light, they're coming!"

"lɛɾ əm kʌm!" ɛɡwin ɹɔɹd, oʊpənɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ðə sɔɹs. blɛsədli, ɪnʌf taɪm hæd pæs tə dʌl ðə fɔkɹut slaɪtli, ən ʃi wɑz eɪbəl tə ɡɹæb ə feɪn tʃɹɪkəl ə ðə paʊɝ. ɪt wɑz taɪni, pɝhæps ðə list əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ʃiɾ ɛvɝ tʃænəld. ʃi wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə wiv ə tʌŋ ʌv ɛɹ tə ʃɪft ə pis ə peɪpɝ. bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi ɪnʌf. ɪt hæd tə bi. "wi wɪl faɪt!"

"Let them come!" Egwene roared, opening herself to the Source. Blessedly, enough time had passed to dull the forkroot slightly, and she was able to grab a faint trickle of the Power. It was tiny, perhaps the least amount of the Power she'd ever channeled. She wouldn't be able to weave a tongue of Air to shift a piece of paper. But it would be enough. It had to be. "We will fight!"

nɪkoʊlə dʒʌst snɪft, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət hɝ. "ju kən bɛɹli tʃænəl, mʌðɝ!" ʃi weɪld. "aɪ kən si ɪt. wi kæn faɪt ðɛm!"

Nicola just sniffed, looking up at her. "You can barely channel, Mother!" she wailed. "I can see it. We can't fight them!"

"wi kən ən wɪl," ɛɡwin sɛd fɝmli. "stænd, nɪkoʊlə! jəɹ ən ɪnɪʃiəɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, nɑɾ ə fɹaɪɾənd mɪlkmeɪd."

"We can and will," Egwene said firmly. "Stand, Nicola! You're an initiate of the Tower, not a frightened milkmaid."

ðə ɡɝl lʊkt ʌp.

The girl looked up.

"aɪ wɪl pɹətɛk ju," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ pɹɑməs."

"I will protect you," Egwene said. "I promise."

ðə ɡɝl sim tə teɪk hɑɹt, ɹaɪzɪŋ. ɛɡwin ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə dɪstən hɔlweɪ wɛɹ ðə blæs hæd hɪt. ɪt wɑz dɑɹk, ðə wɔl læmps ənlɪt, bʌt ʃi θɔt ʃi spɑɾəd ʃædoʊz. ðeɪd bi kʌmɪŋ, ən ðeɪd bi liʃɪŋ ɛni wɪmən ðeɪ faʊnd.

The girl seemed to take heart, rising. Egwene glanced toward the distant hallway where the blast had hit. It was dark, the wall lamps unlit, but she thought she spotted shadows. They'd be coming, and they'd be leashing any women they found.

ɛɡwin tɝn ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən. ʃi kəd stɪl feɪnli hɪɹ skɹimz ðət weɪ. ðeɪ wɝ ðə wʌnz ʃid hɝd dʒʌst æftɝ ʃiɾ əweɪkənd. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ wɛɹ ðə ɡɑɹɾ əɾ əɹ dɔɹ hæd ɡɔn, ən dɪdn ɹɪli kɛɹ.

Egwene turned in the other direction. She could still faintly hear screams that way. They were the ones she'd heard just after she'd awakened. She didn't know where the guard at her door had gone, and didn't really care.

"kʌm," ʃi sɛd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, hoʊldɪŋ tə hɝ taɪni bɪɾ ə ðə paʊɝ laɪk ə dʒɹaʊnɪŋ wʊmən klɪŋɪŋ tə ə ɹɛskju ɹoʊp. nɪkoʊlə fɑloʊd, stɪl snɪfəlɪŋ, bʌt ʃi fɑloʊd. sɛvɹəl moʊməns leɪɾɝ, ɛɡwin dɪskʌvɝd wʌt ʃid hoʊp tə faɪnd. ðə hɔlweɪ wɑz fɪld wɪð ɡɝlz, səm ɪn ðɛɹ waɪt dʒɹɛsəz, ʌðɝz wɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃɪfs. ðə nɑvəsɪz klʌmp təɡɛðɝ, mɛni ʌv əm skɹimɪŋ əɾ itʃ blæs ðət ʃʊk ðə taʊɝ. laɪkli, ðeɪ wɪʃt ðət ðeɪ wɝ daʊn bɪloʊ, wɛɹ ðə nɑvəsɪz'

"Come," she said, striding forward, holding to her tiny bit of the Power like a drowning woman clinging to a rescue rope. Nicola followed, still sniffling, but she followed. Several moments later, Egwene discovered what she'd hoped to find. The hallway was filled with girls, some in their white dresses, others wearing their shifts. The novices clumped together, many of them screaming at each blast that shook the Tower. Likely, they wished that they were down below, where the novices'

kɔɹɾɝz hæd wʌns bɪn.

quarters had once been.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn!" sɛvɹəl ɪkskleɪmd əz ɛɡwin ɛntɝd ðə hɔlweɪ. ðeɪ wɝ ə sɑɹi bʌntʃ, lɪt baɪ kændəlz ɪn tɛɹəfaɪd hænz. ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz spɹaʊɾəd laɪk ɹɑtwʊd mʌʃɹumz ɪn ðə spɹɪŋ.

"The Amyrlin!" several exclaimed as Egwene entered the hallway. They were a sorry bunch, lit by candles in terrified hands. Their questions sprouted like rotwood mushrooms in the spring.

"wʌts hæpənɪŋ?"

"What's happening?"

"ɑɹ wi ʌndɝ ətæk?"

"Are we under attack?"

"ɪz ɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn?"

"Is it the Dark One?"
