ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd əɹ hænz, ən ðə ɡɝlz fɛl mɝsɪfəli saɪlənt. "ðə taʊɝ ɪz ʌndɝ ətæk fɹəm ðə sintʃæn," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kɑm vɔɪs. "ðeɪ hæv kʌm tə kæptʃɝ wɪmən u kən tʃænəl; ðeɪv weɪz ə fɔɹsɪŋ ðoʊz wɪmən tə sɝv ðɛm. ɪts nɑt ðə læs bæɾəl, bʌt wəɹ ɪn ɡɹeɪv deɪnʒɝ. aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə lɛɾ əm teɪk ə sɪŋɡəl wʌn ə ju. jə ɑɹ maɪn."

Egwene raised her hands, and the girls fell mercifully silent. "The Tower is under attack from the Seanchan," she said in a calm voice. "They have come to capture women who can channel; they have ways of forcing those women to serve them. It is not the Last Battle, but we are in grave danger. I don't intend to let them take a single one of you. You are mine."

ðə hɔlweɪ ɡɹu stɪl. ɡɝlz ɡlænst ət hɝ, hoʊpfəl, nɝvəs. ðəɹ wɝ ə ɡʊd fɪfti ʌv ðɛm, pɝhæps mɔɹ. ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə du.

The hallway grew still. Girls glanced at her, hopeful, nervous. There were a good fifty of them, perhaps more. They would have to do.

"nɪkoʊlə, dʒæzmɪn, jitɛɝi, ɪnɑlə," ɛɡwin sɛd, neɪmɪŋ ɔf səm ə ðə mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ə ðə nɑvəsɪz. "kʌm fɔɹwɝd. ðə ɹɛst ə jə peɪ kloʊs ətɛnʃən. aɪm gɑnə titʃ jə sʌmθɪŋ."

"Nicola, Jasmen, Yeteri, Inala," Egwene said, naming off some of the more powerful of the novices. "Come forward. The rest of you pay close attention. I'm going to teach you something."

"wʌt, mʌðɝ?" wʌn ə ðə ɡɝlz æskt.

"What, Mother?" one of the girls asked.

ðɪs hæd bɛɾɝ wɝk, ɛɡwin θɔt. "aɪm gɑnə titʃ jə haʊ tə lɪŋk."

This had better work, Egwene thought. "I'm going to teach you how to link."

ðəɹ wɝ ɡæsps. ðɪs wɑzn ə θɪŋ tɔt tə nɑvəsɪz, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wəd si ðət sʌldəm dɪd nɑt faɪn izi pɪkɪŋz ɪn ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz!

There were gasps. This wasn't a thing taught to novices, but Egwene would see that sul'dam did not find easy pickings in the novices' quarters!

titʃɪŋ ðə mɛθəd tʊk ə wɝisəm lɛŋθ ə taɪm, itʃ moʊmən tɔɹn baɪ mɔɹ blæsts ən mɔɹ skɹimz. ðə nɑvəsɪz wɝ fɹaɪɾənd, ən ðət meɪɾ ɪt dɪfəkəl fəɹ səm ə ðɛm tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, lɛɾ əloʊn lɝn ə nu tɛknik. wʌt hæd teɪkən ɛɡwin oʊnli ə fju tʃɹaɪz tə mæstɝ tʊk ðə nɑvəsɪz ə hɑɹt-paʊndɪŋ faɪv mɪnəts tə bɪɡɪn.

Teaching the method took a worrisome length of time, each moment torn by more blasts and more screams. The novices were frightened, and that made it difficult for some of them to embrace the Source, let alone learn a new technique. What had taken Egwene only a few tries to master took the novices a heart-pounding five minutes to begin.

nɪkoʊlə wɑz ə hɛlp - ʃi hæd bɪn tɔt tə lɪŋk bæk ɪn sɑlədɑɹ - ən kəd hɛlp dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ.

Nicola was a help - she had been taught to link back in Salidar - and could help demonstrating.

əz ðeɪ pɹæktəst, ɛɡwin hæd nɪkoʊlə dʒɔɪn ə sɝkəl wɪð hɝ. ðə jʌŋ nɑvəs oʊpən hɝsɛlf ʌp tə ðə sɔɹs, bʌt steɪd dʒʌst ɑn ðə kʌsp ə sɝɛndɝ ən lɛɾ ɛɡwin pʊl paʊɝ θɹu hɝ. ɪt wɝkt, blɛs ðə laɪt! ɛɡwin fɛlt ə ɹʌʃ ʌv ɪɡzɪlɝeɪʃən əz ðə wʌn paʊɝ - tu lɔŋ dɪnaɪɾ əɹ ɪn minɪŋfəl kwɑntəɾiz - flʌɾəd ɪndə hɝ. haʊ swiɾ ɪt wɑz! ðə wɝld wɑz mɔɹ vaɪbɹən ɝaʊn hɝ, saʊnz mɔɹ swit, kʌlɝz mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl.

As they practiced, Egwene had Nicola join a circle with her. The young novice opened herself up to the Source, but stayed just on the cusp of surrender and let Egwene pull power through her. It worked, bless the Light! Egwene felt a rush of exhilaration as the One Power - too long denied her in meaningful quantities - flooded into her. How sweet it was! The world was more vibrant around her, sounds more sweet, colors more beautiful.

ʃi smaɪld ət ðə θɹɪl ʌv ɪt. ʃi kəd fil nɪkoʊlə, sɛns əɹ fɪɹ, hɝ ɪmoʊʃənz bʌbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ.

She smiled at the thrill of it. She could feel Nicola, sense her fear, her emotions bubbling over.

ɛɡwin hæd bɪn pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪnʌf sɝkəlz tə noʊ haʊ tə sɛpɝeɪt hɝsɛlf fɹəm nɪkoʊlə, bʌɾ ɛɡwin ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət fɝs taɪm, haʊ ʃi hæd fɛl swɛpt ʌp ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ fɑɹ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən hɝsɛlf.

Egwene had been part of enough circles to know how to separate herself from Nicola, but Egwene remembered that first time, how she had felt swept up into something far larger than herself.

ðəɹ wɑz ə spɛʃəl skɪl tə oʊpənɪŋ wʌnsɛlf tə ə sɝkəl. ɪt wɑzn tɛɹəbli dɪfəkəl tə lɝn, bʌt ðeɪ dɪdn əv mʌtʃ taɪm. fɔɹtʃənətli, səm ə ðə ɡɝlz sun pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp. jitɛɝi, ə pətit blɑn stɪl ɪn əɹ naɪtɡaʊn, wɑz fɝst. ɪnɑlə, ə kɑpɝi ən læŋki dəmɑni, fɑloʊd sun æftɝ. ɛɡwin iɡɝli fɔɹmd ə sɝkəl wɪð nɪkoʊlə, ən ðə tu ʌðɝ nɑvəsɪz. paʊɝ flʌɾəd ɪndə hɝ.

There was a special skill to opening oneself to a circle. It wasn't terribly difficult to learn, but they didn't have much time. Fortunately, some of the girls soon picked it up. Yeteri, a petite blonde still in her nightgown, was first. Inala, a coppery and lanky Domani, followed soon after. Egwene eagerly formed a circle with Nicola, and the two other novices. Power flooded into her.

nɛkst, ʃi sɛɾ əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝz tə pɹæktəs. ʃi hæd səm ɪŋklɪŋ, fɹəm dɪskʌʃənz wɪð ðə nɑvəsɪz dʊɹɪŋ əɹ steɪ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, wɪtʃ əmʌŋ əm wɝ ðə moʊst skɪld wɪð wivz ən ðə moʊs lɛvəl-hɛɾəd. ðoʊz wɝn ɔlweɪz ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl, bʌt ðət wʊdn mæɾɝ ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ə sɝkəl bækɪŋ əm ʌp. ɛɡwin hɝidli sɛɾ əm ɪndə ɡɹups, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ haʊ tə æksɛp ðə sɔɹs θɹu ə lɪŋk. hoʊpfəli, ət list səm ə ðɛm wəd fɪɡjɝ ɪɾ aʊt.

Next, she set about getting the others to practice. She had some inkling, from discussions with the novices during her stay in the Tower, which among them were the most skilled with weaves and the most level-headed. Those weren't always the most powerful, but that wouldn't matter if they had a circle backing them up. Egwene hurriedly set them into groups, explaining how to accept the Source through a link. Hopefully, at least some of them would figure it out.

wʌt mæɾɝd wɑz ðəɾ ɛɡwin naʊ hæd ðə paʊɝ. ə fɛɹ mɛʒɝ ʌv ɪt, ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi wɑz əkʌstəm tə wɪθaʊt fɔkɹut. ʃi smaɪld ɪn æntɪsəpeɪʃən, ðən bɪɡæn ə wiv, ðə kəmplɛksəɾi ʌv ɪɾ ɔɪŋ sɛvɹəl ə ðə nɑvəsɪz. "wʌt jə ɑɹ siɪŋ," ɛɡwin wɔɹnd, "ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ðət jə ɑɹ nɑt tə tʃɹaɪ, ivən ðoʊz ə jə liɾɪŋ sɝkəlz. ɪts fɑɹ tu dɪfəkəlt ən deɪnʒɝəs."

What mattered was that Egwene now had the Power. A fair measure of it, almost as much as she was accustomed to without forkroot. She smiled in anticipation, then began a weave, the complexity of it awing several of the novices. "What you are seeing," Egwene warned, "is something that you are not to try, even those of you leading circles. It is far too difficult and dangerous."

ə laɪn ə laɪt splɪt ði ɛɹ ət ði ɛn ə ðə hɔlweɪ, ɹoʊteɪɾɪŋ əpɑn ɪtsɛlf. ʃi hoʊp ðət ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wəɾ oʊpən ɪn ðə ɹaɪt loʊkeɪʃən; ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn sɪuənz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, wɪtʃ hæd bɪn sʌmwʌt veɪɡ, ðoʊ ʃi ɔlsoʊ hæɾ ɪleɪnz ɝɪdʒənəl dɪskɹɪpʃən ə ðə pleɪs.

A line of light split the air at the end of the hallway, rotating upon itself. She hoped that the gateway would open in the right location; she was going on Siuan's instructions, which had been somewhat vague, though she also had Elayne's original description of the place.

"ɔlsoʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd tə ðə nɑvəsɪz ɪn ə stɝn vɔɪs, "ju ɑɹ nɑt tə ɹɪpit ðɪs wiv fəɹ ɛniwʌn wɪθaʊt maɪ ɪkspɹɛs pɝmɪʃən, nɑɾ ivən ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ." ʃi daʊɾɪd ðət wəd bi ən ɪʃu; ðə wiv wɑz kɑmplɛks ən fju nɑvəsɪz wəɾ əv ðə skɪl jɛt tə ɹɪpiɾ ɪt.

"Also," Egwene said to the novices in a stern voice, "you are not to repeat this weave for anyone without my express permission, not even other Aes Sedai." She doubted that would be an issue; the weave was complex and few novices would have the skill yet to repeat it.

"mʌðɝ?" ə hɔk-noʊzd ɡɝl neɪm təmɑlə skwikt. "ɑɹ jə ɪskeɪpɪŋ?" hɝ vɔɪs wɑz ɛdʒd wɪð fɪɹ, ən nɑɾ ə lɪɾəl hoʊp, əz ɪf ɛɡwin maɪt teɪk hɝ, tu.

"Mother?" a hawk-nosed girl named Tamala squeaked. "Are you escaping?" Her voice was edged with fear, and not a little hope, as if Egwene might take her, too.

"noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd fɝmli. "aɪl ɹɪtɝn ɪn dʒʌst ə moʊmənt. wən aɪ kʌm bæk, aɪ wɑn ət lis faɪv ɡʊd sɝkəlz fɔɹmd!"

"No," Egwene said firmly. "I'll return in just a moment. When I come back, I want at least five good circles formed!"

ən wɪð nɪkoʊlə ən əɹ tu ʌðɝ ətɛndəns ɪn toʊ, ɛɡwin stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪndə ə dɑɹk ɹum. ʃi woʊv ə ɡloʊb ə laɪt, ən ði ɪluməneɪʃən ɹɪvild ə stɔɹɹum wɪð ʃɛlvz laɪnɪŋ ðə wɔlz. ʃi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ɹɪliv saɪ. ʃid ɡɑɾən ðə loʊkeɪʃən ɹaɪt.

And with Nicola and her two other attendants in tow, Egwene stepped through the gateway into a dark room. She wove a globe of light, and the illumination revealed a storeroom with shelves lining the walls. She let out a relieved sigh. She'd gotten the location right.

ðoʊz ʃɛlvz, əlɔŋ wɪð tu ʃɔɹt ɹoʊz ə ʃɛlvz aʊɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, wɝ fɪld wɪð aɪɾəmz ə kjʊɹiəs dɪzaɪn. kɹɪstəl ɡlɑbz, smɔl ɪɡzɑɾɪk stætʃuz, hɪɹ ə ɡlæs pɛndənt wɪtʃ ɹəflɛktəd blu ɪn ðə laɪt, ðəɹ ə lɑɹdʒ sɛɾ ə mɛɾəl ɡɔnləts laɪn ət ðə kʌfs wɪð faɪɝdʒɹɑps. ɛɡwin stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum, livɪŋ ðə θɹi nɑvəsɪz tə stɛɹ ɪn wʌndɝ. ðeɪ kəd laɪkli sɛns wʌɾ ɛɡwin nu -  ðiz wɝ ɑbʒɛkts ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ. tɛɹæŋɡɹil, æŋɡɹil, sɑŋɡɹil. ɹɛlɪks ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz.

Those shelves, along with two short rows of shelves out on the floor, were filled with items of curious design. Crystal globes, small exotic statues, here a glass pendant which reflected blue in the light, there a large set of metal gauntlets lined at the cuffs with firedrops. Egwene strode into the room, leaving the three novices to stare in wonder. They could likely sense what Egwene knew -  these were objects of the One Power. Ter'angreal, angreal, sa'angreal. Relics of the Age of Legends.

ɛɡwin skæn ðə ʃɛlvz. aɪɾəmz ə ðə paʊɝ wɝ ɪnfəməsli deɪnʒɝəs tə juz ɪf jə dɪdnt noʊ ɪɡzækli wʌt ðeɪ dɪd. ɛni wʌn ə ðiz aɪɾəmz kəd kɪl hɝ. ɪf oʊnli. . . .

Egwene scanned the shelves. Items of the Power were infamously dangerous to use if you didn't know exactly what they did. Any one of these items could kill her. If only. . . .

ʃi smaɪl bɹɔdli, stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə ə ʃɛlf ən slaɪɾɪŋ ə fluɾəd waɪt wɑn əz lɔŋ əz əɹ fɔɹɑɹm ɔf ðə tɑp ʃɛlf. ʃid faʊn ɪt! ʃi hɛld ɪt ɹɛvɝənli fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən ɹitʃt ən pʊl ðə wʌn paʊɝ θɹu ɪt. ən ɑsəm, ɔlmoʊst oʊvɝpaʊɹɪŋ, tɔɹən ə paʊɝ flʌɾəd θɹu hɝ.

She smiled broadly, stepping up to a shelf and sliding a fluted white wand as long as her forearm off the top shelf. She'd found it! She held it reverently for a moment, then reached and pulled the One Power through it. An awesome, almost overpowering, torrent of power flooded through her.

jitɛɝi ɡæspt ɑɾəbli ət sɛnsɪŋ ɪt. fju wɪmən hæɾ ɛvɝ hɛl sətʃ paʊɝ. ɪt sɝdʒd ɪndə ɛɡwin, laɪk ə dip bɹɛθ dʒɹɔn ɪn. ɪt meɪɾ əɹ lɔŋ tə ɹɔɹ. ʃi lʊkt ət ðə θɹi nɑvəsɪz, smaɪlɪŋ bɹɔdli. "naʊ wɝ ɹɛɾi," ʃi ənaʊnst.

Yeteri gasped audibly at sensing it. Few women had ever held such power. It surged into Egwene, like a deep breath drawn in. It made her long to roar. She looked at the three novices, smiling broadly. "Now we're ready," she announced.

lɛt ðə sʌldəm tʃɹaɪ ən ʃild əɹ waɪl ʃi wɑz wildɪŋ wʌn ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl sɑŋɡɹil ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pəzɛst. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wəd nɑt fɔl waɪl ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn! nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ə faɪt tə ɹaɪvəl ðə læs bæɾəl ɪtsɛlf.

Let the sul'dam try and shield her while she was wielding one of the most powerful sa'angreal that the Aes Sedai possessed. The White Tower would not fall while she was Amyrlin! Not without a fight to rival the Last Battle itself.

sɪuən faʊnd ɡɔɪnz tɛn ɪluməneɪɾəd, ʃædoʊz pleɪɪŋ ɑn ðə wɔlz əz ðə mæn muvd əbaʊɾ ɪnsaɪd. hɪz tɛnt wɑz səspɪʃəsli kloʊz tə ðə ɡɑɹd poʊst; hi wɑz əlaʊd tə steɪ wɪðɪn ðə pælɪsɑd, pɝhæps soʊ ðət bɹaɪn - ən ðə wɑtʃɪŋ ɡɑɹdz - kəd kip ən aɪ ɑn hɪm.

Siuan found Gawyn's tent illuminated, shadows playing on the walls as the man moved about inside. His tent was suspiciously close to the guard post; he was allowed to stay within the palisade, perhaps so that Bryne - and the watching guards - could keep an eye on him.

bɹaɪn, biɪŋ ðə stʌbɝn dɛvəlfɪʃ i wɑz, hæd nɑt ɡɔn tə hɪz ɡɑɹd poʊst əz ʃiɾ ɪnstʃɹʌktəd.

Bryne, being the stubborn devilfish he was, had not gone to his guard post as she'd instructed.

hid fɑloʊd bɪhaɪn hɝ, kɝsɪŋ ən kɔlɪŋ fəɹ ɪz ətɛndəns tə kʌm faɪn hɪm, ɹæðɝ ðən miɾ ɪm ət ðə poʊst. ivən əz ʃi stɑpt ət jʌŋ ɡɔɪnz tɛnt, bɹaɪn stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɝ, hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd. hi aɪɾ əɹ wɪð dɪsæɾɪsfækʃən. wɛl. ʃi wʊdn lɛɾ ɪm bi ðə dʒʌdʒ ə hɝ ɑnɝ! ʃi wəd də wʌt ʃi plizd.

He'd followed behind her, cursing and calling for his attendants to come find him, rather than meet him at the post. Even as she stopped at young Gawyn's tent, Bryne stepped up beside her, hand resting on the hilt of his sword. He eyed her with dissatisfaction. Well. She wouldn't let him be the judge of her honor! She would do what she pleased.

ɔlðoʊ ɪt wɑz laɪkli tə meɪk ɛɡwin vɛɹi, vɛɹi ənɔɪd wɪð hɝ. ʃɪl bi θæŋkfəl ɪn ði ɛnd, sɪuən θɔt. "ɡɔɪn!" ʃi bɑɹkt.

Although it was likely to make Egwene very, very annoyed with her. She'll be thankful in the end, Siuan thought. "Gawyn!" she barked.

ðə hænsəm juθ bɝst aʊɾ ə hɪz tɛnt, hɑpɪŋ əz i stɑmpt ɑn ɪz lɛf but. hi hæɾ ɪz ʃið sɔɹɾ ɪn hænd, sɔɹd bɛl hæf ɑn ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst. "wʌt?" hi æskt, skænɪŋ ðə kæmp. "aɪ hɝd ʃaʊts. ɑɹ wi biɪŋ ətækt?"

The handsome youth burst out of his tent, hopping as he stomped on his left boot. He had his sheathed sword in hand, sword belt half on around his waist. "What?" he asked, scanning the camp. "I heard shouts. Are we being attacked?"

"noʊ," sɪuən sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət bɹaɪn. "bʌt tɑɹ vəlɑn maɪt bi."

"No," Siuan said, glancing at Bryne. "But Tar Valon might be."

"ɛɡwin!" ɡɔɪn kɹaɪd, hɝidli duɪŋ ðə læs lups ɑn ɪz bɛlt. laɪt, bʌt ðə bɔɪ wɑz sɪŋɡəl- maɪndəd.

"Egwene!" Gawyn cried, hurriedly doing the last loops on his belt. Light, but the boy was single- minded.

"bɔɪ," sɪuən sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "aɪ oʊ jə ə dɛt fəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ mi aʊɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. wɪl jə teɪk maɪ hɛlp ɡɛɾɪŋ jə ɪn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əz ɹipeɪmənt?"

"Boy," Siuan said, folding her arms. "I owe you a debt for getting me out of Tar Valon. Will you take my help getting you in to Tar Valon as repayment?"

"ɡlædli!" ɡɔɪn sɛɾ iɡɝli, slaɪɾɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn pleɪs. "ɹipeɪmən ən ðən sʌm!"

"Gladly!" Gawyn said eagerly, sliding his sword in place. "Repayment and then some!"

ʃi nɑɾəd. "ɡoʊ ɡɛɾ əs səm hɔɹsəz, ðɛn. ɪt maɪt dʒʌs bi ðə tu ʌv ʌs."

She nodded. "Go get us some horses, then. It might just be the two of us."

"aɪl ɹɪsk ɪt," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "faɪnəli!"

"I'll risk it," Gawyn said. "Finally!"

"ju woʊn bi teɪkɪŋ maɪ hɔɹsəz fəɹ ðɪs fulz ɛɹənd," bɹaɪn sɛd stɝnli.

"You won't be taking my horses for this fool's errand," Bryne said sternly.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ maʊns ɪn ɪz steɪbəlz oʊn baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɡɔɪn," sɪuən sɛd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ bɹaɪn.

"There are mounts in his stables owned by the Aes Sedai, Gawyn," Siuan said, ignoring Bryne.

"ɡɛt wʌn ə ðɛm fəɹ mi. ə maɪld wʌn, maɪn ju. vɛɹi, vɛɹi maɪld."

"Get one of them for me. A mild one, mind you. Very, very mild."

ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd ən ɹæn əweɪ ɪndə ðə naɪt. sɪuən fɑloʊɾ ɪm əɾ ə mɔɹ kɛɹfəl peɪs, plɑɾɪŋ.

Gawyn nodded and ran away into the night. Siuan followed him at a more careful pace, plotting.

ðɪs wəɾ ɔl bi soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ ɪf ʃi kəd kɹieɪɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ, bʌt ʃi dɪdn əv ɪnʌf stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ fəɹ ðæt. ʃi hæd bɪfɔɹ əɹ stɪlɪŋ, bʌt wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ θɪŋz tə bi dɪfɹənt wɑz əbaʊɾ əz jusfəl əz wɪʃɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝpaɪk jud kɑt wɑz ə fæŋfɪʃ ɪnstɛd. jə soʊld wʌt jə hæɾ ən wɝ hæpi fəɹ ɛni kaɪndə kætʃ əɾ ɔl.

This would all be so much easier if she could create a gateway, but she didn't have enough strength in the Power for that. She had before her stilling, but wishing for things to be different was about as useful as wishing the silverpike you'd caught was a fangfish instead. You sold what you had and were happy for any kind of catch at all.

"sɪuən," bɹaɪn sɛd sɔfli, wɔkɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɝ. kʊdn i dʒʌs lɛɾ əɹ bi! "lɪsən tə mi. ðɪs ɪz ɪnsænəɾi! haʊ ɑɹ jə gɑnə ɡɛɾ ɪn?"

"Siuan," Bryne said softly, walking beside her. Couldn't he just let her be! "Listen to me. This is insanity! How are you going to get in?"

sɪuən ɡlænst ət hɪm. "ʃimɹɪn ɡɑɾ aʊt."

Siuan glanced at him. "Shemerin got out."

"ðæt wɑz bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɑz ə sidʒ, sɪuən." bɹaɪn saʊndəɾ ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd. "ðə pleɪs ɪz mʌtʃ taɪɾɝ naʊ."

"That was before there was a siege, Siuan." Bryne sounded exasperated. "The place is much tighter now."

sɪuən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ʃimɹɪn wɑz biɪŋ wɑtʃt kloʊsli. ʃi ɡɑɾ aʊt θɹu ə wɔɾɝɡeɪt; ɪts ənwɑtʃt əl bɛt, ivən naʊ. aɪd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɪt, ən aɪ wɑz æmɪɝlɪn. aɪ hæv ə mæp tə ɪts loʊkeɪʃən."

Siuan shook her head. "Shemerin was being watched closely. She got out through a watergate; it's unwatched I'll bet, even now. I'd never heard of it, and I was Amyrlin. I have a map to its location."

bɹaɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðən ɪz feɪs hɑɹɾənd. "ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ. ðə tu ʌv jə stɪl əv noʊ tʃæns ɑn jəɹ oʊn."

Bryne hesitated. Then his face hardened. "It doesn't matter. The two of you still have no chance on your own."

"ðɛn kʌm wɪð ʌs," sɪuən sɛd.

"Then come with us," Siuan said.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt bi pɑɹɾi tə jə bɹeɪkɪŋ jəɹ oʊθ əɡɛn."

"I will not be party to you breaking your oath again."

"ɛɡwin sɛd wi kəd də sʌmθɪŋ ɪf ɪt lʊk laɪk ʃi wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ ʌv ɛksəkjuʃən," sɪuən sɛd. "ʃi toʊl mi ʃid lɛɾ əs ɹɛskju hɝ ðɛn! wɛl, ðə weɪ ʃi vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə miɾɪŋ wɪð mi tənaɪt, aɪm ɪnklaɪn tə θɪŋk ʃiz ɪn deɪnʒɝ."

"Egwene said we could do something if it looked like she was in danger of execution," Siuan said. "She told me she'd let us rescue her then! Well, the way she vanished from the meeting with me tonight, I'm inclined to think she's in danger."

"ɪɾ ɪzən ɪleɪɾə hu pʊɾ əɹ ðɛɹ, bʌt ðə sintʃæn!"

"It isn't Elaida who put her there, but the Seanchan!"

"wi doʊnt noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən."

"We don't know for certain."

"ɪɡnɝəns ɪz nɑɾ ən ɪkskjus," bɹaɪn sɛd stɝnli, stɛpɪŋ kloʊsɝ tə hɝ. "ju hæv meɪɾ oʊθbɹeɪkɪŋ fɑɹ tu kənvinjənt, sɪuən, ən aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɪt tə bɪkʌm ə hæbət fəɹ ju. ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ nɑt, fɔɹmɝ æmɪɝlɪn əɹ nɑt, pipəl mʌst əv ɹulz ən baʊndɝiz. tə seɪ nʌθɪŋ ə ðə fæk ðət jəɹ laɪkli tə ɡɛt jɝsɛlf kɪld ətɛmptɪŋ ðɪs!"

"Ignorance is not an excuse," Bryne said sternly, stepping closer to her. "You have made oathbreaking far too convenient, Siuan, and I don't want it to become a habit for you. Aes Sedai or not, former Amyrlin or not, people must have rules and boundaries. To say nothing of the fact that you're likely to get yourself killed attempting this!"

"ænd wɪl jə stɑp mi?" ʃi wɑz stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹs. "du jə θɪŋk jə kəd mænədʒ ɪt?"

"And will you stop me?" She was still holding the source. "Do you think you could manage it?"

hi ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ. bʌɾ i sɛd nʌθɪŋ. sɪuən tɝn ən wɔkt əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, stʃɹeɪt təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝz ət ðə pælɪsɑd ɡeɪt.

He ground his teeth. But he said nothing. Siuan turned and walked away from him, straight toward the fires at the palisade gate.

"blæstəd wʊmən," bɹaɪn sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. "jul bi ðə dɛθ ə mi."

"Blasted woman," Bryne said from behind. "You'll be the death of me."

ʃi tɝnd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ən aɪbɹaʊ.

She turned, raising an eyebrow.

"aɪl kʌm," hi sɛd, hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz ʃið sɔɹd. hi kʌɾ ən ɪmpoʊzɪŋ fɪɡjɝ ɪn ðə naɪt, ðə stʃɹeɪt laɪnz ə hɪz koʊt mætʃɪŋ ðə sɛt kæst ə hɪz feɪs. "bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ tu kəndɪʃənz."

"I'll come," he said, hand gripping the hilt of his sheathed sword. He cut an imposing figure in the night, the straight lines of his coat matching the set cast of his face. "But there are two conditions."

"neɪm ðɛm," ʃi sɛd.

"Name them," she said.

"ðə fɝst ɪz ðət jə bɑn mi əz jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ."

"The first is that you bond me as your Warder."

sɪuən stɑɹɾəd. hi wɑntəd. . . . laɪt! bɹaɪn wɑntəd tə bi hɝ wɔɹɾɝ? ʃi fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ʌv ɪksaɪtmənt.

Siuan started. He wanted. . . . Light! Bryne wanted to be her Warder? She felt a surge of excitement.

bʌt ʃi hædn kənsɪɾɝd teɪkɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ, nɑt sɪns ɔlɹɪks dɛθ. luzɪŋ ɪm hæd bɪn ə tɛɹəbəl ɪkspɪɹiəns. dɪd ʃi wɑnə ɹɪsk ðəɾ əɡɛn?

But she hadn't considered taking a Warder, not since Alric's death. Losing him had been a terrible experience. Did she want to risk that again?

dɪd ʃi dɛɹ pæs ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə hæv ðɪs mæn bɑndəd tə hɝ, tə fil ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz, hæv ɪm baɪ hɝ saɪd? æftɝ ɔl ðət ʃi hæd dʒɹimd ən ɔl ðət ʃi hæd wɪʃt?

Did she dare pass the opportunity to have this man bonded to her, to feel his emotions, have him by her side? After all that she had dreamed and all that she had wished?

filɪŋ ɹɛvɝənt, ʃi stɛp bæk ʌp tə bɹaɪn, ðən leɪɾ ə hæn əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst ən woʊv ðə ɹikwaɪɝd wivz ə spɪɹəɾ ən leɪɾ əm oʊvɝ hɪm. hi bɹiðd ɪn ʃɑɹpli əz nu əwɛɹnəs blɑsəmd ɪnsaɪɾ ə boʊθ ə ðɛm, ə nu kənɛkʃən. ʃi kəd fil ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz, kəd sɛns ɪz kənsɝn fəɹ hɝ, wɪtʃ wɑz ʃɑkɪŋli paʊɝfəl. ɪt wɑz əhɛɾ ə hɪz wɝi fəɹ ɛɡwin ən kənsɝn fəɹ ɪz soʊlʒɝz! oʊ, ɡɛɹɪθ, ʃi θɔt, filɪŋ hɝsɛlf smaɪl ət ðə switnəs ə hɪz lʌv fəɹ hɝ.

Feeling reverent, she stepped back up to Bryne, then laid a hand against his chest and wove the required weaves of Spirit and laid them over him. He breathed in sharply as new awareness blossomed inside of both of them, a new connection. She could feel his emotions, could sense his concern for her, which was shockingly powerful. It was ahead of his worry for Egwene and concern for his soldiers! Oh, Gareth, she thought, feeling herself smile at the sweetness of his love for her.

"aɪ ɔlweɪz wʌndɝd wʌt ðət wəd fil laɪk," bɹaɪn sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hæn ən meɪkɪŋ ə fɪst ə fju taɪmz ɪn ðə tɔɹtʃlaɪt. hi saʊndəɾ əmeɪzd. "wʊd ðəɾ aɪ kəd ɡɪv ðɪs tə itʃ mæn ɪn maɪ ɑɹmi!"

"I always wondered what that would feel like," Bryne said, raising his hand and making a fist a few times in the torchlight. He sounded amazed. "Would that I could give this to each man in my army!"

sɪuən snɪft. "aɪ haɪli daʊt ðət ðɛɹ waɪvz ən fæmliz wəɾ əpɹuv ə ðæt."

Siuan sniffed. "I highly doubt that their wives and families would approve of that."

"ðeɪ wəɾ ɪf ɪt kɛp ðə soʊlʒɝz əlaɪv," bɹaɪn sɛd. "aɪ kəd ɹʌn ə θaʊzən liɡz ən nɛvɝ wɑn fəɹ bɹɛθ. aɪ kəd stæn əɡɛnst ə hʌnʒɹəd foʊz ət wʌns ən læf əɾ əm ɔl."

"They would if it kept the soldiers alive," Bryne said. "I could run a thousand leagues and never want for breath. I could stand against a hundred foes at once and laugh at them all."

ʃi ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz. mɛn! ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə dipli pɝsənəl ən ɪmoʊʃənəl kənɛkʃən tə ənʌðɝ pɝsən - ðə laɪks ʌv wɪtʃ ivən hʌzbənz ən waɪvz wəd nɛvɝ noʊ - ən ɔl i kəd θɪŋk əbaʊt wɑz haʊ mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ i maɪɾ əv bɪkʌm ət sɔɹdpleɪ!

She rolled her eyes. Men! She had given him a deeply personal and emotional connection to another person - the likes of which even husbands and wives would never know - and all he could think about was how much better he might have become at swordplay!

"sɪuən!" ə vɔɪs kɔld. "sɪuən sɑntʃ!"

"Siuan!" a voice called. "Siuan Sanche!"

ʃi tɝnd. ɡɔɪn, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə blæk ɡɛldɪŋ, əpɹoʊtʃt. ənʌðɝ hɔɹs tʃɹɑɾəd bɪhaɪn ɪm - ə ʃæɡi bɹaʊn mɛɹ. "bɛlə!" sɪuən ɪkskleɪmd.

She turned. Gawyn, riding a black gelding, approached. Another horse trotted behind him - a shaggy brown mare. "Bela!" Siuan exclaimed.

"ɪz ʃi suɾəbəl?" ɡɔɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ slaɪtli aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ. "bɛlə wɑz wʌns ɛɡwinz hɔɹs, aɪ ɹikɔl, ən ðə steɪbələmæstɝ sɛd ʃi wɑz ðə moʊs plæsəɾ i hæd."

"Is she suitable?" Gawyn said, sounding slightly out of breath. "Bela was once Egwene's horse, I recall, and the stablemaster said she was the most placid he had."

"ʃil də dʒʌs faɪn," sɪuən sɛd, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə bɹaɪn. "ju sɛd jə hæd tu ɹɪkwaɪɹməns?"

"She'll do just fine," Siuan said, turning back to Bryne. "You said you had two requirements?"

"aɪl tɛl jə ðə sɛkən əɾ ə leɪɾɝ taɪm." bɹaɪn stɪl saʊndəɾ ə lɪɾəl bɹɛθləs.

"I'll tell you the second at a later time." Bryne still sounded a little breathless.

"ðæts ɹæðɝ æmbɪɡjuəs." sɪuən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ɡɪvɪŋ ən oʊpən pɹɑməs."

"That's rather ambiguous." Siuan folded her arms. "I don't like giving an open promise."

"wɛl, jəl əv tə də ɪɾ ɛniweɪ," bɹaɪn sɛd, miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz.

"Well, you'll have to do it anyway," Bryne said, meeting her eyes.

"faɪn, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɛɾɝ nɑt bi ɪndisənt, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn."

"Fine, but it had better not be indecent, Gareth Bryne."

hi fɹaʊnd.

He frowned.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"ɪts ɑd," hi sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "aɪ kən sɛns jəɹ ɪmoʊʃənz naʊ. fəɹ ɪnstəns aɪ kəd tɛl. . . ." hi kʌɾ ɔf, ən ʃi kəd sɛns ɪm ɡɹoʊɪŋ dʒʌs feɪnli ɪmbɛɹəst.

"It's odd," he said, smiling. "I can sense your emotions now. For instance I could tell. . . ." He cut off, and she could sense him growing just faintly embarrassed.

hi kən tɛl ðəɾ aɪ hæf wɑn ɪm tə dɪmæn sʌmθɪŋ ɪndisən ə mi! sɪuən ɹilaɪzd, əɡæst.

He can tell that I half want him to demand something indecent of me! Siuan realized, aghast.

blʌɾi æʃəz! ʃi fɛl hɝsɛlf blʌʃɪŋ. ðɪs wɑz gɑnə bi vɛɹi ɪnkənvinjənt. "oʊ, fəɹ ðə blɛsɪd laɪt. . . . aɪ əɡɹi tə jəɹ tɝmz, jə laʊt. ɡɛt muvɪŋ! wɪv tə ɡoʊ."

Bloody ashes! She felt herself blushing. This was going to be very inconvenient. "Oh, for the Blessed Light. . . . I agree to your terms, you lout. Get moving! We have to go."

hi nɑɾəd. "lɛt mi pɹipɛɹ maɪ kæptənz tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ ɪn keɪs ðə faɪt spɪlz aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi. əl bɹɪŋ ə ɡɑɹɾ ə maɪ bɛs hʌnʒɹəd wɪð ʌs. ðət ʃəd bi smɔl ɪnʌf tə ɡɛɾ ɪn, əsumɪŋ ðɪs ɡeɪt ɹɪli ɪz pæsəbəl."

He nodded. "Let me prepare my captains to take charge in case the fight spills out of the city. I'll bring a guard of my best hundred with us. That should be small enough to get in, assuming this gate really is passable."

"ɪt wɪl bi," ʃi sɛd. "ɡoʊ!"

"It will be," she said. "Go!"

hi æktʃəli  səluɾəd hɝ, hɪz feɪs stʃɹeɪt, bʌt ʃi kəd sɛns ɪz ɪnwɝd ɡɹɪn - ən i laɪkli nu ɪt. ɪnsʌfɝəbəl mæn! ʃi tɝn tə ɡɔɪn, hu sæɾ ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ, lʊkɪŋ kənfjuzd.

He actually saluted her, his face straight, but she could sense his inward grin - and he likely knew it. Insufferable man! She turned to Gawyn, who sat his gelding, looking confused.

"wʌts hæpənɪŋ?" ɡɔɪn æskt.

"What's happening?" Gawyn asked.

"wi doʊn əv tə ɡoʊ ɪn əloʊn." sɪuən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən stil hɝsɛlf əz ʃi klaɪmd ʌp ɪndə bɛləz sæɾəl. hɔɹsəz kʊdn bi tʃɹʌstɪd, nɑɾ ivən bɛlə, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən moʊst. "ðæt minz əɹ tʃænsəz ə sɝvaɪvɪŋ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə teɪk ɛɡwin dʒʌst ɪmpɹuvd. wɪtʃ ɪz fɔɹtʃənət, sɪns æftɝ wʌt wɝ əbaʊt tə du, ʃɪl əndaʊɾɪdli wɑn ðə pɹɪvlədʒ ə kɪlɪŋ əs pɝsənəli."

"We don't have to go in alone." Siuan took a deep breath, then steeled herself as she climbed up into Bela's saddle. Horses couldn't be trusted, not even Bela, though she was better than most. "That means our chances of surviving long enough to take Egwene just improved. Which is fortunate, since after what we're about to do, she'll undoubtedly want the privilege of killing us personally."

ædlɔɹnə bæstin ɹæn θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. fəɹ wʌns, ʃi ɹud ði ɛnhænst sɛnsɪz ðət hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɔfɝd. sɛns simd mɔɹ kɹɪsp tə hɝ, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi kəd smɛl wɝ bɝnɪŋ wʊɾ ən daɪɪŋ flɛʃ. kʌlɝz wɝ mɔɹ vaɪbɹənt, ən ɔl ʃi kəd si wɝ ði æʃən skɑɹz ə bɹoʊkən stoʊn wɛɹ læʃɪz əɹ bɔlz ə fleɪm hæd fɔlən. saʊnz wɝ mɔɹ kɹɪsp, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi hɝd wɝ skɹimz, kɝsɪz, ən ðə ɹɔkəs kɔlz ə ðoʊz hɔɹəbəl bists ɪn ði ɛɹ.

Adelorna Bastine ran through the hallways of the White Tower. For once, she rued the enhanced senses that holding the Power offered. Scents seemed more crisp to her, but all she could smell were burning wood and dying flesh. Colors were more vibrant, and all she could see were the ashen scars of broken stone where lashes or balls of flame had fallen. Sounds were more crisp, but all she heard were screams, curses, and the raucous calls of those horrible beasts in the air.

ʃi skɹæmbəl daʊn ə dɑɹkən hɔlweɪ, hɝ bɹɛθ kʌmɪŋ ɪn ɡæsps, əntɪl ʃi ɹitʃt ən ɪntɝsɛkʃən. ʃi pʊl tə ə stɑp, pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn tə hɝ bɹɛst. ʃi hæd tə faɪn ɹɪzɪstəns. laɪt, ðeɪ kʊdn ɔl əv fɔlən, kəd ðeɪ? ə pɑkəɾ ʌv ɡɹinz hæd stʊd wɪð əɹ ən fɔt. ʃi hæd sin dʒoʊseɪn daɪ əz ə wiv ə ɝθ hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə wɔl bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ən hæd sin mɑɹθɛɹə kæptʃɝd wɪð səm kaɪndə mɛɾəl liʃ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. ædlɔɹnə dɪdnt noʊ wɛɹ əɹ wɔɹɾɝz wɝ. wʌn wɑz wundəd. ənʌðɝ lɪvd. ðə læst . . . ðə læst ʃi dɪdnt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt. laɪt sɛn ðət ʃi kəɾ ət list ɹitʃ ðə wundəd tɔlɹɪk sun.

She scrambled down a darkened hallway, her breath coming in gasps, until she reached an intersection. She pulled to a stop, putting a hand to her breast. She had to find resistance. Light, they couldn't all have fallen, could they? A pocket of Greens had stood with her and fought. She had seen Josaine die as a weave of Earth had destroyed the wall beside her and had seen Marthera captured with some kind of metal leash around her neck. Adelorna didn't know where her Warders were. One was wounded. Another lived. The last . . . the last she didn't want to think about. Light send that she could at least reach the wounded Talric soon.

ʃi pʊl hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fit, waɪpɪŋ blʌd fɹəm əɹ fɔɹhɛd wɛɹ ə tʃɪp ə stoʊn hæd ɡɹeɪz hɝ. ðəɹ wɝ dʒʌst soʊ mɛni ʌv ði ɪnveɪɾɝz, wɪð ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ hɛlməts ən wɪmən juzd əz wɛpənz.

She pulled herself to her feet, wiping blood from her forehead where a chip of stone had grazed her. There were just so many of the invaders, with their strange helmets and women used as weapons.

ən ðeɪ wɝ soʊ skɪld wɪð ðoʊz dɛdli wivz! ædlɔɹnə fɛlt əʃeɪmd. ðə bæɾəl ədʒɑ ɪndid!

And they were so skilled with those deadly weaves! Adelorna felt ashamed. The Battle Ajah indeed!

ðə ɡɹinz wɪð əɹ hæd stʊɾ oʊnli mɪnəts bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ dɪfiɾəd.

The Greens with her had stood only minutes before being defeated.

bɹiðɪŋ hɛvəli, ʃi kəntɪnjud daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. ʃi steɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ði aʊɾɝ ɛdʒ ə ðə taʊɝ, wɛɹ ði ɪnveɪɾɝz wɝ moʊs laɪkli tə bi faʊnd. hæd ʃi lɔs ðə wʌnz u hæd bɪn tʃeɪsɪŋ hɝ? wɛɹ wɑz ʃi? ðə twɛnti-sɛkən lɛvəl? ʃid lɔs kaʊn ə ðə stɛɹwəlz ʃid flɛd θɹu.

Breathing heavily, she continued down the hallway. She stayed away from the outer edge of the Tower, where the invaders were most likely to be found. Had she lost the ones who had been chasing her? Where was she? The twenty-second level? She'd lost count of the stairwells she'd fled through.

ʃi fɹoʊz; ʃi sɛns tʃænəlɪŋ kʌmɪŋ fɹəm əɹ ɹaɪt. ðət kəd min ɪnveɪɾɝz, əɹ ɪt kəd min sɪstɝz. ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌt ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. ʃi wɑz ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ! ʃi kʊdn dʒʌst ɹʌn ən haɪd.

She froze; she sensed channeling coming from her right. That could mean invaders, or it could mean sisters. She hesitated, but gritted her teeth. She was the Captain-General of the Green Ajah! She couldn't just run and hide.

tɔɹtʃlaɪt spɹæŋ fɹəm ðə hɔlweɪ ɪn kwɛstʃən, laɪɾ əkʌmpənid baɪ ɑmənəs ʃædoʊz ə mɛn wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒ ɑɹmɝ. ə skwɑɾ ʌv ɪnveɪɾɝz bɝst ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ən ðeɪ hæɾ ə pɛɹ ʌv wɪmən wɪð ðɛm, ðə wʌnz kənɛktəd baɪ ə liʃ. ædlɔɹnə jɛlp dɪspaɪt hɝsɛlf, dæʃɪŋ əweɪ əz fæst əz əɹ fit kəd kæɹi hɝ. ʃi fɛlt ə ʃil pʊʃ ət hɝ, bʌt ʃi hɛl tə seɪaɪdɑɹ tu fɝmli, ən ɪt dɪdnt ɡɛɾ ɪndə pleɪs bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹaʊndəɾ ə kɔɹnɝ. ʃi kəntɪnjud tə fli, ɡæspɪŋ, deɪzd.

Torchlight sprang from the hallway in question, light accompanied by ominous shadows of men with strange armor. A squad of invaders burst around the corner, and they had a pair of women with them, the ones connected by a leash. Adelorna yelped despite herself, dashing away as fast as her feet could carry her. She felt a shield push at her, but she held to saidar too firmly, and it didn't get into place before she rounded a corner. She continued to flee, gasping, dazed.

ʃi ɹaʊndəɾ ənʌðɝ kɔɹnɝ ən nɪɹli stʌmbəld aʊɾ ʌv ə ɹɪft ɪn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ. ʃi tiɾɝd ɑn ði ɪkspoʊz lɛdʒ, lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ əpɑn ə skaɪ fɪld wɪð tɛɹəbəl mɑnstɝz ən laɪnz ə faɪɝ. ʃi stʌmbəl bæk wɪð ə kɹaɪ, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə hoʊl. ðəɹ wɑz ɹʌbəl tə hɝ ɹaɪt. ʃi skɹæmbəld oʊvɝ ðə ɹɑks. ðə hɔlweɪ kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ! ʃi hæd tə -  ə ʃild ʃʌv bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə sɔɹs, ðɪs taɪm lɑkɪŋ ɪndə pleɪs. ʃi ɡæspt, stʌmbəlɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ʃi wʊdn bi kɑt! ʃi kʊdn bi kɑt! nɑt ðæt!

She rounded another corner and nearly stumbled out of a rift in the side of the Tower. She teetered on the exposed ledge, looking out upon a sky filled with terrible monsters and lines of fire. She stumbled back with a cry, turning away from the hole. There was rubble to her right. She scrambled over the rocks. The hallway continued there! She had to -  A shield shoved between her and the Source, this time locking into place. She gasped, stumbling to the ground. She wouldn't be caught! She couldn't be caught! Not that!

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kəntɪnju fɔɹwɝd, bʌɾ ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ taɪɾənd ɝaʊn əɹ æŋkəl ən dʒɹæɡd əɹ bæk əkɹɔs ðə bɹoʊkən-taɪl flɔɹ. noʊ! ʃi wɑz pʊl dɝɛkli ʌp tə ðə skwɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝz, naʊ əkʌmpənid baɪ tu sɛts ʌv wɪmən kənɛktəd baɪ ðə liʃɪz. ɪn itʃ pɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz ə wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs ən ənʌðɝ ɪn ɹɛɾ ən blu, wɪð ðə laɪtnɪŋ-boʊl pæɾɝn.

She tried to continue forward, but a flow of Air tightened around her ankle and dragged her back across the broken-tiled floor. No! She was pulled directly up to the squad of soldiers, now accompanied by two sets of women connected by the leashes. In each pair there was a woman wearing a gray dress and another in red and blue, with the lightning-bolt pattern.

ənʌðɝ wʊmən əpɹoʊtʃt, wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹɛɾ ən blu. ʃi hɛl sʌmθɪŋ sɪlvɝi ɪn əɹ hænz.

Another woman approached, wearing the red and blue. She held something silvery in her hands.

ædlɔɹnə skɹimd ɪn dɪnaɪəl, pʊʃɪŋ ət ðə ʃild. ðə θɝd wʊmən kɑmli nɛlt ən snæpt ə sɪlvɝ kɑlɝ ɑn ædlɔɹnəz nɛk.

Adelorna screamed in denial, pushing at the shield. The third woman calmly knelt and snapped a silver collar on Adelorna's neck.

ðɪs wɑzn hæpənɪŋ. ɪt kʊdn bi hæpənɪŋ.

This wasn't happening. It couldn't be happening.

"ɑ, vɛɹi naɪs," ðə θɝd wʊmən sɛɾ ɪn ə sloʊ dʒɹɔl. "maɪ neɪm ɪz ɡɹiɡænə, ən jə ʃæl bi sivi. sivi wɪl bi ə ɡʊd deɪmeɪn. aɪ kən si ɪt. aɪ hæv weɪɾəd lɔŋ fəɹ ðɪs moʊmənt, sivi."

"Ah, very nice," the third woman said in a slow drawl. "My name is Gregana, and you shall be Sivi. Sivi will be a good damane. I can see it. I have waited long for this moment, Sivi."

"noʊ," ædlɔɹnə wɪspɝd.

"No," Adelorna whispered.

"jɛs." ɡɹiɡænə smaɪl dipli.

"Yes." Gregana smiled deeply.

ðɛn, ʃɑkɪŋli, ðə kɑlɝ ənklɪp fɹəm ædlɔɹnəz nɛk ən fɛl tə ðə flɔɹ. ɡɹiɡænə lʊk stʌn fəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz kənsumd ɪn ə blæst ə faɪɝ.

Then, shockingly, the collar unclipped from Adelorna's neck and fell to the floor. Gregana looked stunned for a moment before she was consumed in a blast of fire.

ædlɔɹnəz aɪz oʊpənd waɪd, ən ʃi ʃaɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə sʌɾən hit. ə kɔɹps ɪn ə blækən ɹɛɾ ən blu dʒɹɛs kɹʌmbəl tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪfɔɹ hɝ, smoʊkɪŋ ən ɹikɪŋ ə bɝn flɛʃ. ɪt wɑz ðən ðəɾ ædlɔɹnə bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ʌv ən ɪkstʃɹimli paʊɝfəl sɔɹs ə tʃænəlɪŋ kʌmɪŋ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd.

Adelorna's eyes opened wide, and she shied away from the sudden heat. A corpse in a blackened red and blue dress crumbled to the ground before her, smoking and reeking of burned flesh. It was then that Adelorna became aware of an extremely powerful source of channeling coming from behind.

She screamed as she died, and a soldier shouted. It must have been the command to fall back, for the soldiers fled, leaving two frightened women who had been unleashed by the tongues of Air.

Gawyn squatted at the prow of his own boat, the dark waters rippling and lapping at the sides of the vessel. They'd needed thirteen boats to carry them all, and had set into the river quietly and easily  - at least, they had once Siuan Sanche had finished her inspection of the boats and decided they were riverworthy. Barely.

itʃ vɛsəl kæɹiɾ ə sɪŋɡəl, ʃildɪd læntɝn. ɡɔɪn kəd bɛɹli meɪk aʊt ði ʌðɝ boʊts slaɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ði ɛbəni wɔɾɝ, ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹoʊɪŋ əm ɪn nɪɹ saɪləns əz ðeɪ pʊld ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə stoʊnwɝk ɛmbæŋkmən ɑn tɑɹ vəlɑnz saʊθwɛstɝn saɪd. ðə flæʃɪz ə laɪɾ ɪn ðə skaɪ wɝ dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ, ən ɡɔɪn kɛp faɪndɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɡlænsɪŋ ʌp, tə si sɝpəntaɪn bists ɪluməneɪɾəd bɹifli baɪ koʊld waɪt laɪtnɪŋ əɹ bleɪzɪŋ kɹɪmzən faɪɝ.

Each vessel carried a single, shielded lantern. Gawyn could barely make out the other boats sliding over the ebony water, the soldiers rowing them in near silence as they pulled up beside the stonework embankment on Tar Valon's southwestern side. The flashes of light in the sky were distracting, and Gawyn kept finding himself glancing up, to see serpentine beasts illuminated briefly by cold white lightning or blazing crimson fire.

ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf sim tə bɝn. ɪt lɪɾ ə dɔntɪŋ pɹoʊfaɪl ɪn ðə skaɪ, ɔl waɪɾ ən ɹɛd, aʊtlaɪn baɪ fleɪmz. smoʊk bɔɪl təwɔɹd ðə mɪdnaɪt klaʊdz əbʌv, faɪɝz bleɪzd ɪnsaɪd mɛni taʊɝ wɪndoʊz, ən ə ɡlɛɹ ət ðə beɪs ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðəɾ aʊtlaɪɪŋ bɪldɪŋz ən tʃɹiz wɝ ɔlsoʊ əlaɪt.

The White Tower itself seemed to burn. It lit a daunting profile in the sky, all white and red, outlined by flames. Smoke boiled toward the midnight clouds above, fires blazed inside many Tower windows, and a glare at the base indicated that outlying buildings and trees were also alight.

ðə soʊlʒɝz ʃɪpt ɔɹz əz ɡɔɪnz boʊt ɡɹeɪsfəli slɪɾ ʌp bɪsaɪd ðəɾ ə bɹaɪn, pæsɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə lɪp ʌv eɪntʃən stoʊnwɝk wɛɹ ɹɑk oʊvɝhəŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðət blɑkt ɡɔɪnz vju ʌv ðə fjʊɹiəs bæɾəl - ðoʊ hi kəd stɪl hɪɹ ðə ɹʌmbəlɪŋz ən pɑps, ən ən əkeɪʒənəl spɹeɪ ʌv bɹoʊkən stoʊn fɔlɪŋ tə ðə kɑbəlz, saʊndɪŋ laɪk dɪstən ɹeɪn.

The soldiers shipped oars as Gawyn's boat gracefully slid up beside that of Bryne, passing under the lip of ancient stonework where rock overhung the river. That blocked Gawyn's view of the furious battle - though he could still hear the rumblings and pops, and an occasional spray of broken stone falling to the cobbles, sounding like distant rain.

ɡɔɪn ɹeɪzd ɪz læntɝn, ɹɪskɪŋ dʒʌst ə slɪvɝ ə laɪt fɹəm ðə ʃild. wɪð ðəɾ ɪluməneɪʃən, hi kəd meɪk aʊt wʌt bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝ hæd sin. tɑɹ vəlɑnz aɪlənd wɑz ɹɪm baɪ oʊɡiɝ-meɪd bəlwɹks, pɑɹɾ ə ði ɝɪdʒənəl sɪɾi dɪzaɪn; ðeɪ kɛp ði aɪlən fɹəm ɪɹoʊɾɪŋ. laɪk moʊst oʊɡiɝ wɝk, ðə bəlwɹks wɝ bjuɾəfəl. hɪɹ, ðə stoʊn dɛləkətli ɑɹtʃt aʊtwɝd fɹəm ði aɪlən faɪv əɹ sɪks fiɾ əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝ, fɔɹmɪŋ ə lɪp ðət lʊk laɪk ðə waɪt tɪp ʌv ə kɹæʃɪŋ weɪv. ɪn ðə sɑf laɪɾ ʌv ɡɔɪnz læntɝn, ði ʌndɝsaɪdz ə ðoʊz stoʊnz wɝ soʊ ɹiəlɪstɪk, soʊ dɛləkət, ðəɾ ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl wɛɹ stoʊn ɛndəɾ ən ɹɪvɝ bɪɡæn.

Gawyn raised his lantern, risking just a sliver of light from the shield. With that illumination, he could make out what Bryne's soldier had seen. Tar Valon's island was rimmed by Ogier-made bulwarks, part of the original city design; they kept the island from eroding. Like most Ogier work, the bulwarks were beautiful. Here, the stone delicately arched outward from the island five or six feet above the water, forming a lip that looked like the white tip of a crashing wave. In the soft light of Gawyn's lantern, the undersides of those stones were so realistic, so delicate, that it was difficult to tell where stone ended and river began.

wʌn ə ðoʊz stoʊn ɹɪpəlz hɪɾ ə klft, ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɑsəbəl tə spɑɾ ivən fɹəm ðɪs kloʊs ət hænd.

One of those stone ripples hid a cleft, almost impossible to spot even from this close at hand.

bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz wɝ stɪɹɪŋ ɪz boʊɾ ɪndə ðə nɛɹoʊ ɹɪft, wɪtʃ wɑz ɛnkloʊzd ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ən tɑp baɪ stoʊn. sɪuənz boʊt wɛnt nɛkst, ən ɡɔɪn weɪv fəɹ ɪz ɹoʊɝz tə ɡoʊ æftɝ hɝ. ðə ɹɪf tɝn ɪndə ə vɛɹi nɛɹoʊ tʌnəl, ən ɡɔɪn ənʃildɪɾ ɪz læntɝn fɝðɝ, əz bɹaɪn ən sɪuən hæd dʌn əhɛd. ðə laɪkən-kʌvɝd stoʊnz wɝ ɹɪbən ɑn ðə saɪdz baɪ dɑɹk wɔɾɝmɑɹks. ɪn mɛni jɪɹz, ðɪs pæsədʒ wʊɾə bɪn kəmplitli ʌndɝ wɔɾɝ.

Bryne's soldiers were steering his boat into the narrow rift, which was enclosed on both sides and top by stone. Siuan's boat went next, and Gawyn waved for his rowers to go after her. The rift turned into a very narrow tunnel, and Gawyn unshielded his lantern further, as Bryne and Siuan had done ahead. The lichen-covered stones were ribboned on the sides by dark watermarks. In many years, this passage would have been completely under water.

"ɪt wɑz pɹɑbli dɪzaɪn fəɹ wɝkɝz," bɹaɪn sɛd fɹəm ʌp əhɛd, hɪz sɑf vɔɪs ɛkoʊɪŋ ɪn ðə dæmp tʌnəl. ivən ðə muvməns ə ði ɔɹz ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ wɝ æmpləfaɪd, əz wɝ dɪstən dʒɹɪps ən læpɪŋz ə ðə ɹɪvɝ. "tə ɡoʊ aʊɾ ən meɪnteɪn ðə stoʊnwɝk."

"It was probably designed for workers," Bryne said from up ahead, his soft voice echoing in the damp tunnel. Even the movements of the oars in the water were amplified, as were distant drips and lappings of the river. "To go out and maintain the stonework."

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ waɪ ðeɪ bɪlt ɪt," sɪuən sɛd. "aɪm dʒʌst ɡlæɾ ɪts hɪɹ. ən mɔɹɾəfaɪd aɪ dɪdnt noʊ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ɝliɝ. wʌn ə ðə stʃɹɛŋkθs ə tɑɹ vəlɑn əz ɔlweɪz bɪn ðət ðə bɹɪdʒəz meɪk ɪt sɪkjʊɹ.

"I don't care why they built it," Siuan said. "I'm just glad it's here. And mortified I didn't know about it earlier. One of the strengths of Tar Valon has always been that the bridges make it secure.

jə kən kip tʃɹæk ə hu ɡoʊz ɪn ən u ɡoʊz aʊt."

You can keep track of who goes in and who goes out."

bɹaɪn snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli, ðə saʊn ɛkoʊɪŋ daʊn ðə tʌnəl. "ju kən nɛvɝ kəntʃɹoʊl ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ə sɪɾi ðɪs saɪz, sɪuən. ðoʊz bɹɪdʒəz, ɪn ə weɪ, ðeɪ ɡɪv jə ə fɔls sɛns ə kəntʃɹoʊl. ʃʊɹ, fəɹ ən ɪnveɪɾɪŋ ɑɹmi, ðɪs sɪɾi ɪz ɪmpɛnətʃɹəbəl - bʌɾ ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs, taɪɾɝ ðən ə tɪk, kən stɪl əv ə dʌzən hoʊlz bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ fliz tə slɪp θɹu."

Bryne snorted softly, the sound echoing down the tunnel. "You can never control everything in a city this size, Siuan. Those bridges, in a way, they give you a false sense of control. Sure, for an invading army, this city is impenetrable - but a place like this, tighter than a tick, can still have a dozen holes big enough for fleas to slip through."

sɪuən fɛl saɪlənt. ɡɔɪn kɑm hɪmsɛlf, bɹiðɪŋ stɛɾəli. ət list i wɑz faɪnəli duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə hɛlp ɛɡwin. ɪt hæd teɪkən fɑɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən hid wɑntəd. laɪt sɛn ðəɾ i wɑz kʌmɪŋ sun ɪnʌf!

Siuan fell silent. Gawyn calmed himself, breathing steadily. At least he was finally doing something to help Egwene. It had taken far longer than he'd wanted. Light send that he was coming soon enough!

ðə tʌnəl tʃɹɛmbəl fɹəm ə dɪstən ɪksploʊʒən. ɡɔɪn ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət ði ʌðɝ tɛn boʊts, pækt wɪð æpɹɪhɛnsɪv soʊlʒɝz. ðeɪ wɝ ɡlaɪɾɪŋ dɝɛkli ɪndə ə wɔɹ zoʊn wɛɹ boʊθ saɪdz wɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðeɪ wɝ, boʊθ saɪdz hæd lɪɾəl ɹizən tə laɪk ðɛm, ən boʊθ saɪdz wɝ wildɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪt tʊk ə spɛʃəl kaɪndə mæn tə stɛɹ ðoʊz ɑdz ɪn ði aɪz.

The tunnel trembled from a distant explosion. Gawyn glanced over his shoulder at the other ten boats, packed with apprehensive soldiers. They were gliding directly into a war zone where both sides were stronger than they were, both sides had little reason to like them, and both sides were wielding the One Power. It took a special kind of man to stare those odds in the eyes.

"hɪɹ," bɹaɪn sɛd, sɪləuɛɾɪd əɡɛns ðə laɪt. hi ɹeɪzd ə hæn ən hɔltəd ðə laɪn ə boʊts.

"Here," Bryne said, silhouetted against the light. He raised a hand and halted the line of boats.

ðə tʌnəl hæɾ oʊpən ʌp tə ðə ɹaɪt, wɛɹ ə lɛdʒ ə stoʊn - ə lændɪŋ wɪð ə sɛɾ ə stɛɹz - weɪɾəd.

The tunnel had opened up to the right, where a ledge of stone - a landing with a set of stairs - waited.

ðə wɔɾɝi tʌnəl ɪtsɛlf kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn.

The watery tunnel itself continued on.

bɹaɪn stʊd, bɛndɪŋ oʊvɝ, ən stɛpt aʊɾ ɑntu ðə lɛdʒ, mʊɹɪŋ ɪz boʊt tə ə klit. ðə soʊlʒɝz ɪn ɪz boʊt fɑloʊd, itʃ kæɹiɪŋ ə smɔl bɹaʊn pækədʒ. wʌt wɝ ðeɪ? ɡɔɪn hædnt noʊɾəst əm loʊɾɪŋ ðə pækədʒəz ɑn ðə boʊts. wən ðə faɪnəl soʊlʒɝ ɪn ðət boʊt stɛpt aʊt, hi pʊʃt ðə vɛsəl fɔɹwɝɾ ən hændəɾ ɪts toʊ ɹoʊp tə ə soʊlʒɝ ɪn sɪuənz boʊt. əz ðə laɪn kəntɪnjud fɔɹwɝd, ðeɪ taɪɾ itʃ boʊt tə ðə wʌn əhɛɾ ʌv ɪt. ðə læs mæn wəd sɪkjʊɹ ɪz boʊt tə ðə dɑkɪŋ pɪlɝ, ən ɪt wəd hoʊld əm ɔl ɪn pleɪs.

Bryne stood, bending over, and stepped out onto the ledge, mooring his boat to a cleat. The soldiers in his boat followed, each carrying a small brown package. What were they? Gawyn hadn't noticed them loading the packages on the boats. When the final soldier in that boat stepped out, he pushed the vessel forward and handed its tow rope to a soldier in Siuan's boat. As the line continued forward, they tied each boat to the one ahead of it. The last man would secure his boat to the docking pillar, and it would hold them all in place.

ɡɔɪn stɛpt ɑntu ðə stoʊn lɛdʒ wən ɪz tɝn keɪm ən i tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp ðə stɛps, wɪtʃ oʊpən ɪndə ðə flɔɹ ʌv ə smɔl æli. ðɪs ɛntʃɹəns hæd pɹɑbli lɔŋ sɪns bɪn fɝɡɑɾən baɪ ɔl seɪv ðə fju bɛɡɝz u juzd ɪt fəɹ ʃɛltɝ. sɛvɹəl ə ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ taɪɪŋ ʌp ə smɔl ɡɹup ə sətʃ mɛn ət ðə bæk ə ði æliweɪ. ɡɔɪn ɡɹɪməst, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. mɔɹ ɔfən ðən nɑt, bɛɡɝz wəd sɛl sikɹəts tə ɛni hu kɛɹd tə lɪsən, ən nuz ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd soʊlʒɝz snikɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi wəd bi wɝθ ɡʊd kɔɪn fɹəm ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd.

Gawyn stepped onto the stone ledge when his turn came and he trotted up the steps, which opened into the floor of a small alley. This entrance had probably long since been forgotten by all save the few beggars who used it for shelter. Several of the soldiers were tying up a small group of such men at the back of the alleyway. Gawyn grimaced, but said nothing. More often than not, beggars would sell secrets to any who cared to listen, and news of a hundred soldiers sneaking into the city would be worth good coin from the Tower Guard.

bɹaɪn stʊd wɪð sɪuən ət ðə maʊθ ə ði æliweɪ, tʃɛkɪŋ ðə stʃɹiɾ aʊtsaɪd. ɡɔɪn dʒɔɪn ðɛm, hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. ðə stʃɹits wɝ ɛmpti. ðə pipəl noʊ daʊt hɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ hoʊmz, laɪkli pɹeɪɪŋ ðət ðə ɹeɪd wəd sun pæs.

Bryne stood with Siuan at the mouth of the alleyway, checking the street outside. Gawyn joined them, hand on his sword. The streets were empty. The people no doubt hid in their homes, likely praying that the raid would soon pass.

ðə soʊlʒɝz ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ði æli. bɹaɪn kwaɪətli ɔɹɾɝd ə skwɑɾ ə tɛn tə ɡɑɹd ðə boʊts. ðən ðə ɹɛst oʊpən ðə sɑft-lʊkɪŋ bɹaʊn pækədʒəz ðət ɡɔɪn hæd noʊɾəst ɝliɝ ən ɹimuv foʊldəd waɪt tɑbɝdz. ðeɪ pʊl ðiz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɛdz, taɪɪŋ əm ət ðə weɪst. itʃ wɑz mɑɹkt wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn.

The soldiers gathered in the alley. Bryne quietly ordered a squad of ten to guard the boats. Then the rest opened the soft-looking brown packages that Gawyn had noticed earlier and removed folded white tabards. They pulled these over their heads, tying them at the waist. Each was marked with the flame of Tar Valon.

ɡɔɪn wɪsəl sɔfli, ðoʊ sɪuən stʊd wɪð ɑɹmz əkɪmboʊ, lʊkɪŋ ɪndɪɡnənt. "wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡɛt ðoʊz?"

Gawyn whistled softly, though Siuan stood with arms akimbo, looking indignant. "Where did you get those?"

"aɪ hæd ðə wɪmən ɪn ði aʊɾɝ kæmp meɪk ðɛm," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ɪts ɔlweɪz ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə tə hæv ə fju kɑpiz ə jəɹ ɛnəmiz junəfɔɹm."

"I had the women in the outer camp make them," Bryne said. "It's always a good idea to have a few copies of your enemy's uniform."

"ɪts nɑt pɹɑpɝ," sɪuən sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. "sɝvɪŋ ɑn ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾ ɪz ə seɪkɹəd duɾi.

"It's not proper," Siuan said, folding her arms. "Serving on the Tower Guard is a sacred duty.

ðeɪ - "

They - "

"ðeɪɹ jəɹ ɛnəmi, sɪuən," bɹaɪn sɛd stɝnli. "fɔɹ naʊ, ət list. jəɹ nɑɾ æmɪɝlɪn ɛnimɔɹ."

"They're your enemy, Siuan," Bryne said sternly. "For now, at least. You're not Amyrlin anymore."

ʃi aɪd hɪm, bʌt hɛld əɹ tʌŋ. bɹaɪn lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə soʊlʒɝz, ðən nɑɾəd ɪn əpɹuvəl. "ðɪs woʊn ful ɛniwʌn ʌp kloʊs, bʌt fɹəm ə dɪstəns, ɪɾəl sɝv. aʊɾ ɑntu ðə stʃɹits ən fɔl ɪndə ɹæŋks.

She eyed him, but held her tongue. Bryne looked over the soldiers, then nodded in approval. "This won't fool anyone up close, but from a distance, it will serve. Out onto the streets and fall into ranks.

hʌsəl təwɔɹd ðə taʊɝ, əz ɪf jəɹ ɹʌʃɪŋ tə hɛlp wɪð ðə bæɾəl. sɪuən, ə ɡloʊb ə laɪɾ əɹ tu wəd hɛlp wɪð ðə dɪsɡaɪz - ɪf ðoʊz u si əs ɔlsoʊ si ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɾ əɹ hɛd, ðəl bi mɔɹ laɪkli tə əsum wʌt wi wɑn əm tə."

Hustle toward the Tower, as if you're rushing to help with the battle. Siuan, a globe of light or two would help with the disguise - if those who see us also see an Aes Sedai at our head, they'll be more likely to assume what we want them to."

ʃi snɪft, bʌt dɪɾ əz ɹɪkwɛstɪd, kɹieɪɾɪŋ tu ɡlɑbz ə laɪt, ðən sɛɾɪŋ əm tə floʊɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ hɛd. bɹaɪn ɡeɪv ðə kəmænd, ən ði ɪntaɪɝ ɡɹup spɪld aʊɾ ə ði æli ən fɔɹmd ɹæŋks. ɡɔɪn, sɪuən ən bɹaɪn tʊk ʌp pəzɪʃənz ət ðə fɹʌnt - ɡɔɪn ən ðə dʒɛnɝəl wɔkɪŋ dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə sɪuən, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wɔɹɾɝz - ən ðeɪ dʌbəl-taɪm fɔɹwɝd daʊn ðə stʃɹit.

She sniffed, but did as requested, creating two globes of light, then setting them to float in the air beside her head. Bryne gave the command, and the entire group spilled out of the alley and formed ranks. Gawyn, Siuan and Bryne took up positions at the front - Gawyn and the general walking just ahead of Siuan, as if they were Warders - and they double-timed forward down the street.

ɔl ɪn ɔl, ði ɪluʒən wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊd. ɑn fɝst ɡlæns, ɡɔɪn hɪmsɛlf wʊɾə bɑt ðə dɪsɡaɪz. wʌt wəd bi mɔɹ nætʃɹəl tə si ðən ə skwɑdʒɹən ə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd mɑɹtʃɪŋ tə ðə sin ə ði ətæk, ɡaɪɾəd baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝz? ɪt wɑz sɝɾənli bɛɾɝ ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə snik ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn θɹu ðə sɪɾi ɪn æliweɪz, ənsin.

All in all, the illusion was very good. On first glance, Gawyn himself would have bought the disguise. What would be more natural to see than a squadron of Tower Guard marching to the scene of the attack, guided by an Aes Sedai and her Warders? It was certainly better than trying to sneak a hundred men through the city in alleyways, unseen.

əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə naɪtmɛɹ. ðə bɪloʊɪŋ smoʊk ɹəflɛktəd ɹɛd faɪɹlaɪt, ɪnvɛləpɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ɪn ə mɛnəsɪŋ kɹɪmzən heɪz. hoʊlz ən ɡæʃəz bɹoʊk ðə wɔlz ə ðə wʌns-mədʒɛstɪk bɪldɪŋ; faɪɝz bleɪzd wɪðɪn sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm. ɹeɪkən kəmændəd ði ɛɹ, swupɪŋ ən spɪnɪŋ əbaʊt ðə taʊɝ laɪk ɡʌlz sɝkəlɪŋ ə dɛd weɪl ɪn ðə weɪvz. skɹimz ən ʃaʊts pɝmieɪɾɪd ði ɛɹ, ən ðə θɪk, ækɹɪd smoʊk meɪd ɡɔɪnz θɹoʊɾ ɪtʃ.

As they approached the Tower grounds they entered the nightmare. The billowing smoke reflected red firelight, enveloping the Tower in a menacing crimson haze. Holes and gashes broke the walls of the once-majestic building; fires blazed within several of them. Raken commanded the air, swooping and spinning about the Tower like gulls circling a dead whale in the waves. Screams and shouts permeated the air, and the thick, acrid smoke made Gawyn's throat itch.

bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz sloʊɾ əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt. ðəɹ sim tə bi tu pɔɪns ə kɑmbæɾ ɪn ðə ɹeɪd. ðə beɪs ə ðə taʊɝ, wɪð ɪts tu flæŋkɪŋ wɪŋz, ʃoʊd flæʃɪz ə laɪt. ðə ɡɹaʊnz wɝ lɪɾɝd wɪð ðə dɛɾ ən ðə wundəd. ən ʌp əbʌv, nɪɹ ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə taʊɝ, sɛvɹəl ɡæʃəz wɝ spjuɪŋ faɪɝbɔlz ən laɪtnɪŋ bæk aʊɾ ət ði ɪnveɪɾɝz. ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taʊɝ sim saɪlən ən dɛd, ðoʊ ʃʊɹli faɪɾɪŋ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz.

Bryne's soldiers slowed as they approached. There seemed to be two points of combat in the raid. The base of the Tower, with its two flanking wings, showed flashes of light. The grounds were littered with the dead and the wounded. And up above, near the middle of the Tower, several gashes were spewing fireballs and lightning back out at the invaders. The rest of the Tower seemed silent and dead, though surely fighting was going on in the corridors.

ðə ɡɹup pʊl tə ə hɔlt aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz' aɪɝn ɡeɪts. ðoʊz ɡeɪts wɝ oʊpən ən kəmplitli ənɡɑɹɾɪd. ðət simd ɑmənəs. "naʊ wʌt?" ɡɔɪn wɪspɝd.

The group pulled to a halt outside the Tower grounds' iron gates. Those gates were open and completely unguarded. That seemed ominous. "Now what?" Gawyn whispered.

"wi faɪn ɛɡwin," sɪuən ænsɝd. "wi stɑɹɾ ət ðə beɪs, ðən hɛd daʊn tə ðə beɪsmən flɔɹz.

"We find Egwene," Siuan answered. "We start at the base, then head down to the basement floors.

ʃi wɑz lɑk daʊn ðəɹ sʌmwɛɹ ɝliɝ tədeɪ, ən ɪts pɹɑbli ðə fɝs pleɪs wi ʃəd lʊk."

She was locked down there somewhere earlier today, and it's probably the first place we should look."

ə spɹeɪ ʌv stoʊn tʃɪps fɛl fɹəm ðə silɪŋ ən ɹeɪn daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl əz ðə waɪt taʊɝ ʃʊk fɹəm jɛɾ ənʌðɝ blæst. sɹɪn kɝs tə hɝsɛlf, waɪpɪŋ ðə tʃɪps əweɪ, ðən ənɹoʊld ə waɪd pis ə pɑɹtʃmənt, weɪɾɪŋ ðə saɪdz wɪð səm bɹoʊkən tʃʌŋks ə taɪl.

A spray of stone chips fell from the ceiling and rained down on the table as the White Tower shook from yet another blast. Saerin cursed to herself, wiping the chips away, then unrolled a wide piece of parchment, weighting the sides with some broken chunks of tile.

ɝaʊn hɝ, ðə ɹum wɑz ɪn vɝtʃuəl keɪɑs. ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ, ɪn ðə fɔɹwɝd ɡæðɝɪŋ ɹum, ə lɑɹdʒ skwɛɹ tʃeɪmbɝ sɪtʃueɪɾɪd wɛɹ ði istɝn wɪŋ mɛt ðə taʊɝ pɹɑpɝ.

Around her, the room was in virtual chaos. They were on the ground floor, in the forward gathering room, a large square chamber situated where the eastern wing met the Tower proper.

mɛmbɝz ə ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd pʊl teɪbəlz aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ tə meɪk ɹum fəɹ ðə ɡɹups pæsɪŋ θɹu. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛɹəli ɡlænst aʊt ðə wɪndoʊz, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə skaɪz. wɔɹɾɝz stɔk laɪk keɪdʒd ænəməlz. wʌt wɝ ðeɪ tə də əbaʊt flaɪɪŋ bists? ðɛɹ bɛs pleɪs wɑz hɪɹ, ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɑpɝeɪʃənz. sətʃ əz ɪt wɑz. sɹɪn hæɾ oʊnli dʒʌst ɝaɪvd.

Members of the Tower Guard pulled tables out of the way to make room for the groups passing through. Aes Sedai warily glanced out the windows, watching the skies. Warders stalked like caged animals. What were they to do about flying beasts? Their best place was here, guarding the center of operations. Such as it was. Saerin had only just arrived.

ə sɪstɝ ɪn ɡɹin swɛpt ʌp tə hɝ. mɹædʒɹi wɑz ə lɔŋ-lɪmd minɝ wɪð dɑɹk skɪn, ən ʃi wɑz tʃɹeɪl baɪ tu hænsəm wɔɹɾɝz, boʊθ ɔlsoʊ minɝ. ɹumɝz sɛd ðət ðeɪ wɝ əɹ bɹʌðɝz, kʌm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə dɪfɛn ðɛɹ sɪstɝ, ðoʊ mɹædʒɹi dɪdn spik ə ðə mæɾɝ.

A sister in green swept up to her. Moradri was a long-limbed Mayener with dark skin, and she was trailed by two handsome Warders, both also Mayener. Rumors said that they were her brothers, come to the White Tower to defend their sister, though Moradri didn't speak of the matter.

sɹɪn dɪmændəd, "haʊ mɛni?"

Saerin demanded, "How many?"

"ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ əz ət lis fɔɹɾi-sɛvən sɪstɝz," mɹædʒɹi sɛd. "spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ði ədʒəz.

"The ground floor has at least forty-seven sisters," Moradri said. "Spread across the Ajahs.

ðæts ðə bɛs kaʊn aɪ kəd ɡæðɝ, əz ðəɹ faɪɾɪŋ ɪn smɔl ɡɹups. aɪ toʊld əm wi wɝ ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ ə fɔɹməl kəmæn sɛntɝ hɪɹ. moʊst sim tə θɪŋk ðət wɑz ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə, ðoʊ mɛni wɝ tu taɪɝd, tu ʃɑkt əɹ tu deɪz tə ɹɪspɑnd wɪð mʌtʃ ɛls bɪsaɪdz ə nɑd."

That's the best count I could gather, as they're fighting in small groups. I told them we were organizing a formal command center here. Most seemed to think that was a good idea, though many were too tired, too shocked or too dazed to respond with much else besides a nod."

"mɑɹk ðɛɹ loʊkeɪʃənz ɑn ðə mæp hɪɹ," sɹɪn sɛd. "dɪd jə faɪn ɪleɪɾə?"

"Mark their locations on the map here," Saerin said. "Did you find Elaida?"

mɹædʒɹi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

Moradri shook her head.

"blæst," sɹɪn mʌɾɝd əz ðə taʊɝ ʃʊk əɡɛn. "wʌɾ ʌv ɛni ɡɹin sɪɾɝz?"

"Blast," Saerin muttered as the Tower shook again. "What of any Green Sitters?"

"aɪ dɪdn faɪn ɛni," mɹædʒɹi sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ɑbviəsli iɡɝ tə ɡɛt bæk tə ðə faɪɾɪŋ.

"I didn't find any," Moradri said, glancing over her shoulder, obviously eager to get back to the fighting.

"ə pɪɾi," sɹɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ laɪk tə kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə bæɾəl ədʒɑ, æftɝ ɔl. wɛl, ðət livz mi tə ɔɹɡənaɪz ðə faɪɾɪŋ."

"A pity," Saerin said. "They like to call themselves the Battle Ajah, after all. Well, that leaves me to organize the fighting."

mɹædʒɹi ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ səpoʊz." ʃi ɡlænst oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əɡɛn.

Moradri shrugged. "I suppose." She glanced over her shoulder again.

sɹɪn aɪd ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ, ðən tæp ðə mæp. "mɑɹk ðə loʊkeɪʃənz, mɹædʒɹi. jə kən bi bæk tə ðə faɪɾɪŋ sun ɪnʌf, bʌt jəɹ nɑlədʒ ɪz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɹaɪt naʊ."

Saerin eyed the Green sister, then tapped the map. "Mark the locations, Moradri. You can be back to the fighting soon enough, but your knowledge is more important right now."

ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ saɪd, bʌt kwɪkli bɪɡæn tə meɪk noʊteɪʃənz ɑn ðə mæp. əz ʃi wɝkt, sɹɪn wɑz pliz tə noʊt kæptən tʃʌbn ɛntɝɪŋ. ðə mæn lʊk juθfəl fəɹ ɪz fɔɹɾi-sʌm wɪntɝz, wɪθaʊɾ ə spɛk ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn ɪz blæk hɛɹ. səm mɛn wɝ ɪnklaɪn tə dɪspɛɹɪdʒ ɪz əbɪləɾiz kəz ə hɪz tu-pɹɪɾi feɪs; sɹɪn hæd hɝɾ ə ðə hjumɪlieɪʃən ðoʊz mɛn hæd ɹəsiv baɪ hɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ði ɪnsʌls.

The Green sister sighed, but quickly began to make notations on the map. As she worked, Saerin was pleased to note Captain Chubain entering. The man looked youthful for his forty-some winters, without a speck of gray in his black hair. Some men were inclined to disparage his abilities because of his too-pretty face; Saerin had heard of the humiliation those men had received by his sword in return for the insults.

"ɑ, ɡʊd," ʃi sɛd. "faɪnəli sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ wɛl. kæptən, oʊvɝ hɪɹ ɪf jə wɪl."

"Ah, good," she said. "Finally something is going well. Captain, over here if you will."

hi lɪmpt oʊvɝ, feɪvɝɪŋ ɪz lɛf lɛɡ. hɪz waɪt tɑbɝd, hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ meɪl, wɑz skɔɹtʃt; hɪz feɪs wɑz smʌdʒd wɪð sʊt. "sɹɪn sədaɪ," hi sɛd, boʊɪŋ.

He limped over, favoring his left leg. His white tabard, hanging over mail, was scorched; his face was smudged with soot. "Saerin Sedai," he said, bowing.

"ju ɑɹ wundəd."

"You are wounded."

"æn ɪŋkɑnsəkwɛntʃəl waʊnd, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪn ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv ə faɪt sətʃ əz ðɪs."

"An inconsequential wound, Aes Sedai, in the glory of a fight such as this."

"si jɝsɛlf hild ɛniweɪ," ʃi ɔɹɾɝd. "ɪt wəd bi ɹɪdɪkjələs fəɹ əɹ kæptən ə ðə ɡɑɹd tə ɹɪsk dɛθ kəz ʌv ən 'ɪŋkɑnsəkwɛntʃəl' waʊnd. ɪf ɪt meɪks jə stʌmbəl fəɹ ə moʊmənt wi kəd luz ju."

"See yourself Healed anyway," she ordered. "It would be ridiculous for our captain of the guard to risk death because of an 'inconsequential' wound. If it makes you stumble for a moment we could lose you."

ðə mæn stɛp kloʊsɝ, spikɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. "sɹɪn sədaɪ, ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾ ɪz ɔl bʌt jusləs ɪn ðɪs faɪt. wɪð ðə sintʃæn juzɪŋ ðoʊz . . . mɑnstʃɹəs wɪmən, wi kən bɛɹli ɹitʃ əm bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ ɹɪp tə pisəz əɹ blæstəd tə æʃəz."

The man stepped closer, speaking in a low voice. "Saerin Sedai, the Tower Guard is all but useless in this fight. With the Seanchan using those . . . monstrous women, we can barely reach them before being ripped to pieces or blasted to ashes."

"ju nid tə tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ tæktɪks, ðɛn, kæptən," sɹɪn sɛd fɝmli. laɪt, wʌɾ ə mɛs! "tɛl ðə mɛn tə swɪtʃ tə baʊz. də nɑt ɹɪsk kloʊzɪŋ ɑn ði ɛnəmiz tʃænlɝz. ʃut fɹəm ə dɪstəns. ə sɪŋɡəl æɹoʊ kəd tɝn ðə bæɾəl tə əɹ saɪd; wɪv ðɛɹ soʊlʒɝz ɡɹoʊsli aʊtnʌmbɝd."

"You need to change your tactics, then, Captain," Saerin said firmly. Light, what a mess! "Tell the men to switch to bows. Do not risk closing on the enemy's channelers. Shoot from a distance. A single arrow could turn the battle to our side; we have their soldiers grossly outnumbered."

"jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Yes, Aes Sedai."

"æz ə waɪt maɪt seɪ, ɪts sɪmpəl lɑdʒɪk," ʃi sɛd. "kæptən, əɹ moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt tæsk ɪz tə fɔɹm ə sɛntɝ ʌv ɑpɝeɪʃənz. ɛɛs sədaɪ ən soʊlʒɝz əlaɪk ɑɹ skɹæmbəlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪndɪpɛndənli, æktɪŋ laɪk ɹæts feɪs baɪ wʊlvz. wi nid tə stæn təɡɛðɝ."

"As a White might say, it's simple logic," she said. "Captain, our most important task is to form a center of operations. Aes Sedai and soldiers alike are scrambling about independently, acting like rats faced by wolves. We need to stand together."

wʌt ʃi dɪdn mɛnʃən wɑz haʊ ɪmbɛɹəst ʃi wɑz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd spɛn sɛntʃɝiz ɡaɪɾɪŋ kɪŋz ən ɪnfluənsɪŋ wɔɹz, bʌt naʊ - wɪð ðɛɹ sæŋktʃuɛɹi əsɔltɪd - ðeɪ hæd pɹuvən woʊfəli ɪnæɾəkwət ɪn dɪfɛndɪŋ ɪt. ɛɡwin wɑz ɹaɪt, ʃi θɔt. nɑt dʒʌst ɪn pɹɪdɪktɪŋ ðɪs ətæk, bʌɾ ɪn bɪɹeɪɾɪŋ əs fəɹ biɪŋ dɪvaɪɾəd. sɹɪn dɪdnt nid ɹɪpɔɹts fɹəm mɹædʒɹi əɹ skaʊts tə noʊ ðət ði ədʒəz wɝ itʃ faɪɾɪŋ ðɪs bæɾəl ɪndɪpɛndənli.

What she didn't mention was how embarrassed she was. The Aes Sedai had spent centuries guiding kings and influencing wars, but now - with their sanctuary assaulted - they had proven woefully inadequate in defending it. Egwene was right, she thought. Not just in predicting this attack, but in berating us for being divided. Saerin didn't need reports from Moradri or scouts to know that the Ajahs were each fighting this battle independently.

"kæptən," ʃi sɛd. "mɹædʒɹi sədaɪ ɪz mɑɹkɪŋ pɑkəts ə faɪɾɝz ɑn ðə mæp. æsk əɹ wɪtʃ ədʒɑ ɪz ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾ ɪn itʃ ɡɹup; ʃiz ən ɛksələn mɛmɹi, ən wɪl bi eɪbəl tə tɛl jə spɪsɪfɪks.

"Captain," she said. "Moradri Sedai is marking pockets of fighters on the map. Ask her which Ajah is represented in each group; she has an excellent memory, and will be able to tell you specifics.

sɛn ɹʌnɝz ɪn maɪ əθɔɹəɾi tə ɛni ɡɹup ə jɛloʊ əɹ bɹaʊn sɪstɝz. tɛl əm tə ɹipɔɹt hɪɹ, tə ðɪs tʃeɪmbɝ.

Send runners in my authority to any group of Yellow or Brown sisters. Tell them to report here, to this chamber.

"nɛkst, sɛn ɹʌnɝz tə ði ʌðɝ ɡɹups ən tɛl əm ðət wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə sɛnd wʌn bɹaʊn əɹ jɛloʊ sɪstɝ tə ðɛm fəɹ hilɪŋ pɝpəsəz. ðəɹ wɪl ɔlsoʊ bi ə ɡɹup ə sɪstɝz hɪɹ pɹəvaɪɾɪŋ hilɪŋ. ɛniwʌn wundəɾ ɪz tə ɹipɔɹt hɪɹ ɪmiɾiətli."

"Next, send runners to the other groups and tell them that we are going to send one Brown or Yellow sister to them for Healing purposes. There will also be a group of sisters here providing Healing. Anyone wounded is to report here immediately."

hi səluɾəd.

He saluted.

"oʊ," ʃi æɾəd. "æn sɛn sʌmwʌn tə ði aʊɾɝ ɡɹaʊnz tə spɑt ðə meɪn bɹitʃɪz əbʌv. wi nid tə noʊ wɛɹ ði ɪnveɪʒən ɪz dipəst."

"Oh," she added. "And send someone to the outer grounds to spot the main breaches above. We need to know where the invasion is deepest."

"ɛɛs sədaɪ, . . ." hi sɛd. "ði aʊɾɝ ɡɹaʊnz ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs. ðoʊz flaɪɪŋ əbʌv faɪɝ ɑn ɛniwʌn ðeɪ si muvɪŋ."

"Aes Sedai, . . ." he said. "The outer grounds are dangerous. Those flying above fire on anyone they see moving."

"ðɛn sɛn mɛn u ɑɹ ɡʊɾ ət kənsilɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz," ʃi ɡɹaʊld.

"Then send men who are good at concealing themselves," she growled.

"jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ. wi - "

"Yes, Aes Sedai. We - "

"ðɪs ɪz ə dɪzæstɝ!" ən æŋɡɹi vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd.

"This is a disaster!" an angry voice shouted.

sɹɪn tɝn tə faɪn fɔɹ ɹɛd sɪstɝz ɛntɝɪŋ ðə ɹum. noʊtæʃə wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə waɪt dʒɹɛs blʌɾid ʌp ðə lɛf saɪd, ðoʊ ɪf ðə blʌd wɑz əɹ oʊn, ʃid bɪn hild. keɪɾɝinz mæs ə lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ wɑz fɹæzəld ən tæŋɡəld wɪð tʃɪps ə stoʊn. ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən wɔɹ ɹɪp dʒɹɛsəz, feɪsəz sɔɪld wɪð æʃ.

Saerin turned to find four Red sisters entering the room. Notasha was wearing a white dress bloodied up the left side, though if the blood was her own, she'd been Healed. Katerine's mass of long black hair was frazzled and tangled with chips of stone. The other two women wore ripped dresses, faces soiled with ash.

"haʊ dɛɹ ðeɪ stʃɹaɪk hɪɹ!" keɪɾɝin kəntɪnjud, kɹɔsɪŋ ðə ɹum. soʊlʒɝz dʌkt aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ, ən sɛvɹəl lɛs-ɪnfluɛntʃəl sɪstɝz u hæd ɡæðɝɾ ət sɹɪnz ɔɹɾɝ sʌɾənli faʊn θɪŋz tə də ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə ðə ɹum. dɪstən bumz saʊndəd, laɪk ðə nɔɪzɪz ʌv ən ɪluməneɪɾɝz dɪspleɪ.

"How dare they strike here!" Katerine continued, crossing the room. Soldiers ducked out of her way, and several less-influential sisters who had gathered at Saerin's order suddenly found things to do at the corners of the room. Distant booms sounded, like the noises of an Illuminator's display.

"ðeɪ dɛɹ kəz ðeɪv ðə minz ən ðə dɪzaɪɝ, ɑbviəsli," sɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd, ʃʌvɪŋ daʊn əɹ ənɔɪəns ən meɪnteɪnɪŋ əɹ kɑm. wɪð dɪfəkəlti. "soʊ fɑɹ, ðə stʃɹaɪk əz pɹuvən ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ɪfɛktɪv."

"They dare because they have the means and the desire, obviously," Saerin replied, shoving down her annoyance and maintaining her calm. With difficulty. "So far, the strike has proven remarkably effective."

"wɛl, ɪm əsumɪŋ kəmæn hɪɹ," keɪɾɝin ɡɹaʊld. "wi nid tə skaʊɝ ðə taʊɝ ən ɪlɪməneɪɾ itʃ ə ðɛm!"

sɹɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "sɪns wən dɪd ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz aʊtʃɹæŋk ə sɪɾɝ ɪn ðə hɔl, keɪɾɝin?"

itʃ feɪsləs sintʃæn ðəɾ ɛɡwin stʃɹʌk daʊn sim tə bi ɹɛnə ɪn əɹ maɪnz aɪ. ɛɡwin stʊɾ əɾ ən oʊpən hoʊl ɪn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wɪn pʊlɪŋ əɾ əɹ waɪt dʒɹɛs, tʌɡɪŋ əɾ əɹ hɛɹ, haʊlɪŋ əz ɪf ɪn əkʌmpnɪmən tə hɝ ɹeɪdʒ.

Each faceless Seanchan that Egwene struck down seemed to be Renna in her mind's eye. Egwene stood at an open hole in the side of the White Tower, wind pulling at her white dress, tugging at her hair, howling as if in accompaniment to her rage.

hɝ æŋɡɝ wɑz nɑɾ aʊɾ ə kəntʃɹoʊl. ɪt wɑz koʊld ən dɪstɪld. ðə taʊɝ wɑz bɝnɪŋ. ʃi hæd fɔɹtoʊl ðɪs, ʃi hæd dʒɹimd ɪt, bʌt ðə ɹiæləɾi wɑz fɑɹ wɝs ðən ʃi hæd fɪɹd. ɪf ɪleɪɾə hæd pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ði ɪvɛnt, ðə dæmədʒ wʊɾə bɪn mʌtʃ lɛs. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn lɔŋɪŋ fəɹ wʌt hæd nɑt bɪn.

Her anger was not out of control. It was cold and distilled. The Tower was burning. She had Foretold this, she had Dreamed it, but the reality was far worse than she had feared. If Elaida had prepared for the event, the damage would have been much less. But there was no point in longing for what had not been.

ɪnstɛd, ʃi dɝɛktəɾ əɹ æŋɡɝ - ði æŋɡɝ ə dʒʌstəs, ðə ɹæθ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn. ʃi blæstəd tɔɹeɪkən æftɝ tɔɹeɪkən fɹəm ði ɛɹ. ðeɪ wɝ mʌtʃ lɛs mənuvɝəbəl ðən ðɛɹ smɔlɝ kʌzənz.

Instead, she directed her anger - the anger of justice, the wrath of the Amyrlin. She blasted to'raken after to'raken from the air. They were much less maneuverable than their smaller cousins.

ʃi mʌst əv fɛld ə dʌzən baɪ naʊ, ən əɹ ækʃənz hæd dʒɹɔn ði ətɛnʃən ə ðoʊz aʊtsaɪd. ði ətæk bɪloʊ wɑz bɹeɪkɪŋ ɔf, ði ɪntaɪɝ ɹeɪd foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ɛɡwin. ðə nɑvəsɪz fɔt sintʃæn ɹeɪɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz ɑn ðə stɛɹz, fɔɹsɪŋ əm bæk. tɔɹeɪkən wɪŋd əbaʊɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ, swupɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə taʊɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk ɛɡwin wɪð ʃilz əɹ blæsts ə faɪɝ. smɔlɝ ɹeɪkən dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ði ɛɹ, kɹɔsboʊmən ɑn ðɛɹ bæks lɔntʃɪŋ boʊls ət hɝ.

She must have felled a dozen by now, and her actions had drawn the attention of those outside. The attack below was breaking off, the entire raid focusing on Egwene. Smaller raken darted through the air, crossbowmen on their backs launching bolts at her.

bʌt ʃi wɑz ə faʊn ə paʊɝ, dʒɹɔn fɹəm dip wɪðɪn ðə fluɾəd ɹɑɾ ɪn əɹ hænz, tʃænəl θɹu ə ɡɹup ə nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹum bɪhaɪnd, baʊn tə hɝ ɪn sɝkəl. ɛɡwin wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə faɪɝz ðət bɝn ɪn ðə taʊɝ, blʌɾiɪŋ ðə skaɪ wɪð ðɛɹ fleɪmz, peɪntɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɪð ðɛɹ smoʊk. ʃi ɔlmoʊst sim nɑɾ ə biɪŋ ə flɛʃ, bʌt wʌn ə pjʊɹ paʊɝ, sɛndɪŋ dʒʌdʒmən tə ðoʊz u hæd dɛɹd bɹɪŋ wɔɹ tə ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. blæsts ə laɪtnɪŋ stɔɹm fɹəm ðə skaɪ, ðə klaʊdz tʃɝnɪŋ əbʌv. faɪɝ spɹaʊɾəd fɹəm əɹ hænz.

But she was a fount of Power, drawn from deep within the fluted rod in her hands, channeled through a group of novices and Accepted hiding in the room behind, bound to her in circle. She almost seemed not a being of flesh, but one of pure Power, sending judgment to those who had dared bring war to the Tower itself. pɝhæps ʃi ʃʊɾə fɪɹd bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə θɹi oʊðz. bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt. ðɪs wɑz ə faɪt ðət niɾəd tə bi fɔt, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt lʌs fəɹ dɛθ - ðoʊ, pɝhæps, hɝ ɹeɪdʒ əɡɛns ðə sʌldəm əpɹoʊtʃt ɪt. ðə soʊlʒɝz ən deɪmeɪn wɝ ənfɔɹtʃənət kæʒəwəltiz.

Perhaps she should have feared breaking the Three Oaths. But she did not. This was a fight that needed to be fought, and she did not lust for death - though, perhaps, her rage against the sul'dam approached it. The soldiers and damane were unfortunate casualties.

The White Tower, the sacred dwelling of the Aes Sedai, was under attack. They were all in danger, a danger greater than death. Those silvery collars were far worse. Egwene defended herself and each woman in the Tower.
