ɡɛɹɪθ dɑdʒ tə ðə saɪd, ɹoʊlɪŋ wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt, bɹɛstpleɪt dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə hɪz saɪdz ən bɛli əz i hɪt kɑbəlstoʊnz. sʌmθɪŋ mæsɪv ɪn ði ɛɹ pæs dʒʌst əbʌv hɪm, ən ə θəɾɪŋ kɹæʃ fɑloʊd.

Gareth dodged to the side, rolling with a grunt, breastplate digging into his sides and belly as he hit cobblestones. Something massive in the air passed just above him, and a thudding crash followed.

hi keɪm ʌp ɑn wʌn ni tə si ə bɝnɪŋ ɹeɪkən tʌmbəlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɛɹ i hæd bɪn stændɪŋ, ɪts ɹaɪɾɝ - ɔlɹɛɾi dɛd fɹəm ðə faɪɝəbləs ðət hæd kɪld ɪz maʊnt - tʌmbəlɪŋ fɹi laɪk ə ɹæɡ dɑl. ðə ɹeɪkən kɔɹps, stɪl smoʊldɝɪŋ, slʌmp tə ə ɹɛs bɪsaɪd ðə taʊɝ wɔl. ðə ɹaɪɾɝ leɪ wɛɹ i hæd fɔlən, ðə hɛlm baʊnsɪŋ əweɪ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. wʌn ə ðə kɔɹpsəz buts wɑz mɪsɪŋ.

He came up on one knee to see a burning raken tumbling across the ground where he had been standing, its rider - already dead from the fireblast that had killed his mount - tumbling free like a rag doll. The raken corpse, still smoldering, slumped to a rest beside the Tower wall. The rider lay where he had fallen, the helm bouncing away into the darkness. One of the corpse's boots was missing.

bɹaɪn hiv hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fiɾ ən pʊld ɪz bɛl naɪf fɹi - hid dʒɹɑpt ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ðə ɹoʊl. hi spʌn, skænɪŋ fəɹ deɪnʒɝ. ðəɹ wɑz plɛnti ʌv ɪt tə bi faʊnd. ɹeɪkən swupt - bɪɡ wʌnz ən smɔl wʌnz - ðoʊ moʊst wɝ fɪkseɪɾɪd ɑn ðə taʊɝ əbʌv. ði ɪnɝ ɡɹin ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə taʊɝ wɑz stʌɾɪd wɪð tʃʌŋks ə stoʊn ən bɑɾiz twɪstəɾ ɪndə hɔɹɪfɪk pəzɪʃənz. bɹaɪnz mɛn wɝ faɪɾɪŋ ə skwɑdʒɹən ə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz; ði ɪnveɪɾɝz ɪn ðɛɹ ɪnsɛktəl ɑɹmɝ hæd paɪld aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ moʊməns əɡoʊ. wɝ ðə sintʃæn ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm sʌmθɪŋ əɹ dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə faɪt?

Bryne heaved himself to his feet and pulled his belt knife free - he'd dropped his sword in the roll. He spun, scanning for danger. There was plenty of it to be found. Raken swooped - big ones and small ones - though most were fixated on the Tower above. The inner green at the front of the Tower was studded with chunks of stone and bodies twisted into horrific positions. Bryne's men were fighting a squadron of Seanchan soldiers; the invaders in their insectile armor had piled out of the Tower moments ago. Were the Seanchan running away from something or just looking for a fight?

ðəɹ wɝ ə ɡʊd θɝɾi ʌv ðɛm.

There were a good thirty of them.

hæd ðə soʊlʒɝz kʌm aʊt tə ðɪs kɔɹtʃjɑɹd tə bi lɪftəɾ əweɪ? wɛl, iðɝ weɪ, ðeɪ hæd mɛɾ ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd fɔɹs ɪn bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz. laɪt bi blɛsɪd, ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃænlɝz ɪn ðə ɡɹup.

Had the soldiers come out to this courtyard to be lifted away? Well, either way, they had met an unexpected force in Bryne's soldiers. Light be blessed, there were no channelers in the group.

wɪð oʊvɝ tu-tə-wʌn ɑdz, bɹaɪnz mɛn ʃʊɾə hæɾ ən izi taɪm ʌv ɪt. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðəɹ wɝ səm fju ʌv ðə bɪɡɝ ɹeɪkən əbʌv dʒɹɑpɪŋ stoʊnz ən faɪɝbɔlz ɑn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz ɑkjəpəns.

With over two-to-one odds, Bryne's men should have had an easy time of it. Unfortunately, there were some few of the bigger raken above dropping stones and fireballs on the courtyard's occupants.

ən ðiz sintʃæn fɔt wɛl. vɛɹi wɛl.

And these Seanchan fought well. Very well.

bɹaɪn kɔl fəɹ ɪz mɛn tə stæn fæst, ɡlænsɪŋ əbaʊt fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd. ɡɔɪn - ðə wʌn u hæd wɔɹn ɪm ɝliɝ - stʊd nɪɹ ɪt, dulɪŋ tu sintʃæn ət wʌns. hæd ðə bɔɪ noʊ sɛns? ɡɔɪnz fɔɹs hæd ði ʌpɝ hænd. hi ʃəɾ əv ə sɔɹdmeɪt wɪð hɪm. hi -  ɡɔɪn dɪspætʃt boʊθ sintʃæn wɪð wʌn fluəd moʊʃən. wɑz ðət loʊɾəs kloʊzɪz ɪts blɑsəm?

Bryne called for his men to stand fast, glancing about for his sword. Gawyn - the one who had warned him earlier - stood near it, dueling two Seanchan at once. Had the boy no sense? Gawyn's force had the upper hand. He should have a swordmate with him. He -  Gawyn dispatched both Seanchan with one fluid motion. Was that Lotus Closes Its Blossom?

bɹaɪn hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪt juz soʊ ɪfɛktɪvli əɡɛns tu mɛn ət wʌns. ɡɔɪn waɪpt ɪz wɛpən əz pɑɹɾ ə ðə tʃɹədɪʃənəl fɪnɪʃɪŋ flɝɪʃ, ðən ʃiðd ɪɾ ən kɪk bɹaɪnz fɔlən sɔɹɾ ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ ən snætʃt ɪt. hi fɛl ɪndə ə ɡɑɹd pəzɪʃən, hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹd, wɛɹi. bɹaɪnz laɪn ə mɛn wɑz hoʊldɪŋ, dɪspaɪt ði ətæks fɹəm əbʌv. ɡɔɪn nɑɾəd tə bɹaɪn, weɪvɪŋ ɪm fɔɹwɝd wɪð ðə sɔɹd.

Bryne had never seen it used so effectively against two men at once. Gawyn wiped his weapon as part of the traditional finishing flourish, then sheathed it and kicked Bryne's fallen sword up into the air and snatched it. He fell into a guard position, holding the sword, wary. Bryne's line of men was holding, despite the attacks from above. Gawyn nodded to Bryne, waving him forward with the sword.

mɛɾəl ɑn mɛɾəl ɹæŋ əkɹɔs ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ʃædoʊz θɹoʊn əkɹɔs ðə skɑɹd ɡɹæs, lɪt baɪ ðə faɪɝz əbʌv. bɹaɪn tʊk ɪz sɔɹd bæk ən ɡɔɪn ənʃiðd ɪz oʊn bleɪd, ɑn ɛdʒ. "lʊk ʌp ðɛɹ," hi sɛɾ ən pɔɪntəd wɪð ɪz sɔɹd.

Metal on metal rang across the courtyard, shadows thrown across the scarred grass, lit by the fires above. Bryne took his sword back and Gawyn unsheathed his own blade, on edge. "Look up there," he said and pointed with his sword.

bɹaɪn skwɪntɪd. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv æktɪvəɾi nɪɹ ə hoʊl ɪn wʌn ə ði ʌpɝ flɔɹz. hi pʊl fɹi hɪz spaɪɡlæs, foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ðə loʊkeɪʃən, tʃɹʌstɪŋ ɪn ɡɔɪn tə wɔɹn ɪm ɪf deɪnʒɝ əpɹoʊtʃt.

Bryne squinted. There was a great deal of activity near a hole in one of the upper floors. He pulled free his spyglass, focusing on the location, trusting in Gawyn to warn him if danger approached.

"baɪ ðə laɪt . . ." bɹaɪn wɪspɝd, foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡæp. ə sɑlətɛɹi fɪɡjɝ wɛɹɪŋ waɪt stʊɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝz ɹɛnt. ɪt wɑz tu dɪstən tə meɪk aʊɾ əɹ feɪs, ivən wɪð ðə spaɪɡlæs, bʌt huɛvɝ ʃi wɑz, ʃi wɑz sɝɾənli duɪŋ səm dæmədʒ tə ðə sintʃæn. hɝ ɑɹmz wɝ əpɹeɪzd wɪð faɪɝ ɡloʊɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ hænz, ðə bɝnɪŋ laɪt θɹoʊɪŋ ʃædoʊz əkɹɔs ði aʊɾɝ taʊɝ wɔl ɝaʊn hɝ. blæsts ə faɪɝ flu ɪn ə stɛɾi stʃɹim, flɪŋɪŋ ɹeɪkən fɹəm ðə skaɪ.

"By the Light . . ." Bryne whispered, focusing on the gap. A solitary figure wearing white stood in the Tower's rent. It was too distant to make out her face, even with the spyglass, but whoever she was, she was certainly doing some damage to the Seanchan. Her arms were upraised with fire glowing between her hands, the burning light throwing shadows across the outer Tower wall around her. Blasts of fire flew in a steady stream, flinging raken from the sky.

hi ɹeɪzd ɪz spaɪɡlæs haɪɝ, skænɪŋ ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə taʊɝ, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ʌðɝ saɪnz ə ɹɪzɪstəns. ðəɹ wɑz æktɪvəɾi ɑn ðə flæt, sɝkjəlɝ ɹuf. ɪt wɑz soʊ dɪstən i kəd bɛɹli meɪk ɪɾ aʊt.

He raised his spyglass higher, scanning the length of the Tower, searching for other signs of resistance. There was activity on the flat, circular roof. It was so distant he could barely make it out.

ɪt lʊk laɪk poʊlz biɪŋ ɹeɪzd, fɑloʊd baɪ ɹeɪkən swupɪŋ daʊn ən . . . wʌt? itʃ taɪm ə ɹeɪkən swup baɪ, ɪt lɛf dʒɹæɡɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ.

It looked like poles being raised, followed by raken swooping down and . . . What? Each time a raken swooped by, it left dragging something.

kæptɪvz, bɹaɪn ɹilaɪzd wɪð ə tʃɪl. ðəɹ teɪkɪŋ kæptɪv ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ðə ɹuf, taɪɪŋ ɹoʊps tə ðɛm, ðən ðə ɹeɪkən ɑɹ snætʃɪŋ ðoʊz ɹoʊps ən toʊɪŋ ðə wɪmən ɪndə ði ɛɹ. laɪt! hi kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ʌv wʌn ə ðə kæptɪvz biɪŋ pʊld əweɪ. ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ə sæk taɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd.

Captives, Bryne realized with a chill. They're taking captive Aes Sedai to the roof, tying ropes to them, then the raken are snatching those ropes and towing the women into the air. Light! He caught a glimpse of one of the captives being pulled away. It looked as if she had a sack tied over her head.

"wi hæv tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə taʊɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ðɪs faɪɾ ɪz dʒʌst ə dɪstʃɹækʃən."

"We have to get into the Tower," Gawyn said. "This fight is just a distraction."

"əɡɹid," bɹaɪn sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ ðə spaɪɡlæs. hi ɡlæns tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, wɛɹ sɪuən hæd sɛd ʃid weɪt waɪl ðə mɛn fɔt. taɪm tə kəlɛkt əɹ ən -  ʃi wɑz ɡɔn. bɝn fɛlt ə spaɪk ə ʃɑk, fɑloʊd baɪ wʌn ə tɛɹɝ. wɛɹ wɑz ʃi? ɪf ðət wʊmən hæd ɡɑɾən hɝsɛlf kɪld. . . .

"Agreed," Bryne said, lowering the spyglass. He glanced to the side of the courtyard, where Siuan had said she'd wait while the men fought. Time to collect her and -  She was gone. Byrne felt a spike of shock, followed by one of terror. Where was she? If that woman had gotten herself killed. . . .

bʌt noʊ. hi kəd sɛns əɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə taʊɝ. ʃi wɑzn hɝt. ðɪs bɑnd wɑz sətʃ ə wʌnʒɹəs θɪŋ, bʌɾ i wɑz tu ʌnəkʌstəm tə ɪt. hi ʃʊɾə noʊɾəst ðət ʃi wɑz ɡɔn! hi skæn ɪz laɪn ə soʊlʒɝz. ðə sintʃæn hæd fɔt wɛl, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ vɪzəbli ɹuɾəd naʊ. ðɛɹ laɪn wɑz bɹeɪkɪŋ, skæɾɝɪŋ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz, ən bɹaɪn bɑɹk ði ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ ɪz mɛn nɑt tə fɑloʊ.

But no. He could sense her inside the Tower. She wasn't hurt. This bond was such a wondrous thing, but he was too unaccustomed to it. He should have noticed that she was gone! He scanned his line of soldiers. The Seanchan had fought well, but they were visibly routed now. Their line was breaking, scattering in all directions, and Bryne barked the order for his men not to follow.

"fɝst ən sɛkən skwɑdz, ɡæðɝ ðə wundəd kwɪkli," hi kɔld. "kæɹi ðɛm tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ðoʊz u kən wɔk ʃəd hɛd dɝɛkli fəɹ ðə boʊts." hi ɡɹɪməst. "ðoʊz u kænt wɔk wɪl nid tə weɪt fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hil ðɛm." ðə soʊlʒɝz nɑɾəd. ðə bædli wundəd wəd bi əbændən ɪndə ɛnəmi hænz, bʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn wɔɹn ə ðət pɑsəbɪləɾi bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ ɑn ðɪs mɪʃən. ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn aʊtweɪɾ ɔl ʌðɝ kənsɝnz.

"First and second squads, gather the wounded quickly," he called. "Carry them to the side of the courtyard. Those who can walk should head directly for the boats." He grimaced. "Those who can't walk will need to wait for Aes Sedai to Heal them." The soldiers nodded. The badly wounded would be abandoned into enemy hands, but they had been warned of that possibility before coming on this mission. Recovering the Amyrlin outweighed all other concerns.

səm mɛn wəd daɪ fɹəm ðɛɹ wunz waɪl ðeɪ weɪɾəd. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i kəd də əbaʊt ðæt. hoʊpfəli, moʊst wəd bi hil baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðət hilɪŋ wəd bi fɑloʊd baɪ ɪmpɹɪzənmənt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs. ðə tim ə soʊlʒɝz hæd tə kip muvɪŋ kwɪkli, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ lɪɾɝz tə kæɹi ðə wundəd.

Some men would die from their wounds while they waited. There was nothing he could do about that. Hopefully, most would be Healed by the White Tower Aes Sedai. That healing would be followed by imprisonment, but there was no other choice. The team of soldiers had to keep moving quickly, and there was no time for litters to carry the wounded.

"θɝɾ ən fɔɹθ skwɑdz," hi bɪɡæn, ɝdʒənt. hi stɑpt əz ə fəmɪljɝ fɔɹm ɪn ə blu dʒɹɛs stʃɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, toʊɪŋ ə ɡɝl ɪn waɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, sɪuən hɝsɛlf lʊkt oʊnli feɪnli oʊldɝ ðən ðə ɡɝl, naʊ. ət taɪmz, hi hæd dɪfəkəlti kənɛktɪŋ əɹ tə ðə stɝn wʊmən i hæd mɛt jɪɹz əɡoʊ.

"Third and fourth squads," he began, urgent. He stopped as a familiar form in a blue dress strode out of the Tower, towing a girl in white. Of course, Siuan herself looked only faintly older than the girl, now. At times, he had difficulty connecting her to the stern woman he had met years ago.

filɪŋ ə sɝdʒ ə ɹɪlif, hi kənfɹʌntəd sɪuən əz ʃi əpɹoʊtʃt. "hu ɪz ðæt?" hi dɪmændəd.

Feeling a surge of relief, he confronted Siuan as she approached. "Who is that?" he demanded.

"wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡoʊ?"

"Where did you go?"

ʃi klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ, tɛlɪŋ ðə nɑvəs tə weɪt, ðən pʊlɪŋ bɹaɪn əweɪ tə spik tə hɪm ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. "jɔɹ soʊlʒɝz wɝ bɪzi, ən aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wəd bi ə ɡʊd taɪm tə ɡæðɝ səm ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ænd, aɪ maɪt noʊt, wɝ gɑnə hæv tə wɝk ɑn jəɹ æɾətud, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. ðæts nɑt ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪ fəɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ tə spik tə hɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ."

She clicked her tongue, telling the novice to wait, then pulling Bryne away to speak to him in a low voice. "Your soldiers were busy, and I decided it would be a good time to gather some information. And, I might note, we're going to have to work on your attitude, Gareth Bryne. That's not the proper way for a Warder to speak to his Aes Sedai."

"aɪl stɑɹt wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðət wən jə stɑɹɾ æktɪŋ laɪk juv tu bɪts ə sɛns ɪn jəɹ hɛd, wʊmən. wʌɾ ɪf jud ɹʌn ɪndə sintʃæn?"

"I'll start worrying about that when you start acting like you have two bits of sense in your head, woman. What if you'd run into Seanchan?"

"ðɛn aɪ wʊɾə bɪn ɪn deɪnʒɝ," ʃi sɛd, hænz ɑn hɪps. "ɪt wʊdn bi ðə fɝs taɪm. aɪ kʊdn ɹɪsk biɪŋ sin baɪ ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð jə əɹ jəɹ soʊlʒɝz. sətʃ sɪmpəl dɪsɡaɪzɪz woʊn ful ə sɪstɝ."

"Then I would have been in danger," she said, hands on hips. "It wouldn't be the first time. I couldn't risk being seen by other Aes Sedai with you or your soldiers. Such simple disguises won't fool a sister."

"æn ɪf jud bɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd?" hi dɪmændəd. "sɪuən, ðiz pipəl tʃɹaɪd tə ɛksəkjut ju!"

"And if you'd been recognized?" he demanded. "Siuan, these people tried to execute you!"

ʃi snɪft. "mɔɪɹeɪn hɝsɛlf wʊdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mi wɪð ðɪs feɪs. ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ wɪl dʒʌst si ə jʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ hu lʊks feɪnli fəmɪljɝ. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ dɪdn ɹʌn ɪndə ɛni ʌv ðɛm. dʒʌs ðɪs tʃaɪld." ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə nɑvəs; ðə ɡɝl hæɾ ə ʃɔɹt bɑb ə blæk hɛɹ ən stɛɹd, tɛɹəfaɪd, ət ðə bæɾəl ɪn ðə skaɪ əbʌv. "hæʃɑlə, kʌm hɪɹ," sɪuən kɔld.

She sniffed. "Moiraine herself wouldn't recognize me with this face. The women in the Tower will just see a young Aes Sedai who looks faintly familiar. Besides, I didn't run into any of them. Just this child." She glanced at the novice; the girl had a short bob of black hair and stared, terrified, at the battle in the sky above. "Hashala, come here," Siuan called.

ðə nɑvəs skɝiɾ oʊvɝ.

The novice scurried over.

"tɛl ðɪs mæn wʌt jə toʊl mi," sɪuən kəmændəd.

"Tell this man what you told me," Siuan commanded.

"jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ðə nɑvəs sɛd wɪð ən æŋkʃəs kɝtsi. bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz meɪɾ ən ɑnɝ ɡɑɹɾ ɝaʊn sɪuən, ən ɡɔɪn stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd bɹaɪn. ðə jʌŋ mænz aɪz kɛp flɪkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɛdli skaɪ.

"Yes, Aes Sedai," the novice said with an anxious curtsy. Bryne's soldiers made an honor guard around Siuan, and Gawyn stepped up beside Bryne. The young man's eyes kept flicking toward the deadly sky.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," ðə nɑvəs sɛɾ ɪn ə kwɪvɝɪŋ vɔɪs. "ʃi wɑz ɹilis fɹəm ðə sɛlz ɝliɝ tədeɪ ən əlaʊd tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz. aɪ wɑz daʊn ɪn ðə loʊɝ kɪtʃənz wən ði ətæk keɪm, soʊ aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ əz hæpən tə hɝ. bʌt ʃiz pɹɑbli ʌp ɑn ðə twɛnti-fɝst əɹ twɛnti-sɛkən lɛvəl sʌmwɛɹ. ðæts wɛɹ ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz ɑɹ naʊ." ʃi ɡɹɪməst. "ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ɪz ə mɛs, ðiz deɪz. nʌθɪŋ ɪz wɛɹ ɪt ʃəd bi."

"The Amyrlin, Egwene al'Vere," the novice said in a quivering voice. "She was released from the cells earlier today and allowed to return to the novices' quarters. I was down in the lower kitchens when the attack came, so I don't know what has happened to her. But she's probably up on the twenty-first or twenty-second level somewhere. That's where the novices' quarters are now." She grimaced. "The inside of the Tower is a mess, these days. Nothing is where it should be."

sɪuən mɛt bɹaɪnz aɪz. "ɛɡwinz bɪn ɡɪvən fɔkɹuɾ ɪn hɛvi doʊsəz. ʃɪl bɛɹli bi eɪbəl tə tʃænəl."

Siuan met Bryne's eyes. "Egwene's been given forkroot in heavy doses. She'll barely be able to channel."

"wiv ɡɑt tə ɹitʃ hɝ!" ɡɔɪn sɛd.

"We've got to reach her!" Gawyn said.

"ɑbviəsli," bɹaɪn sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "ðæts waɪ wɝ hɪɹ. aɪ ɡɛs wi ɡoʊ ʌp ɪnstɛɾ ə daʊn, ðɛn."

"Obviously," Bryne said, rubbing his chin. "That's why we're here. I guess we go up instead of down, then."

"jɔɹ hɪɹ tə ɹɛskju hɝ, ɑɹən ju?" ðə nɑvəs saʊndəɾ iɡɝ.

"You're here to rescue her, aren't you?" The novice sounded eager.

bɹaɪn aɪd ðə ɡɝl. tʃaɪld, aɪ wɪʃ jə hædn meɪd ðət kənɛkʃən. hi heɪɾəd ðə θɔɾ ə livɪŋ ə mɪɹ nɑvəs taɪɾ ʌp ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðɪs mɛs. bʌt ðeɪ kʊdn əv əɹ ɹʌnɪŋ tə ɡɪv wɔɹnɪŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Bryne eyed the girl. Child, I wish you hadn't made that connection. He hated the thought of leaving a mere novice tied up in the middle of this mess. But they couldn't have her running to give warning to the White Tower Aes Sedai.

"aɪ wɑnə ɡoʊ wɪð ju," ðə nɑvəs sɛd fɝvənli. "aɪm lɔɪəl tə ði æmɪɝlɪn. ðə ɹil æmɪɝlɪn.

"I want to go with you," the novice said fervently. "I'm loyal to the Amyrlin. The real Amyrlin.

moʊst ʌv əs ɑɹ."

Most of us are."

bɹaɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, ɡlænsɪŋ ət sɪuən.

Bryne raised an eyebrow, glancing at Siuan.

"lɛɾ əɹ kʌm," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd. "ɪts ði iziɝ ɑpʃən ɛniweɪ." ʃi muvd oʊvɝ tə bɪɡɪn æskɪŋ ðə ɡɝl ə fju mɔɹ kwɛstʃənz.

"Let her come," the Aes Sedai said. "It's the easier option anyway." She moved over to begin asking the girl a few more questions.

bɹaɪn ɡlæns tə ðə saɪɾ əz wʌn ə hɪz kæptənz, ə mæn neɪm vɛstəz, əpɹoʊtʃt. "maɪ lɔɹd,"

Bryne glanced to the side as one of his captains, a man named Vestas, approached. "My Lord,"

vɛstəz sɛɾ ɝdʒənli, hɪz vɔɪs ə dip wɪspɝ. "ðə wundəɾ ɑɹ sɔɹɾɪd. wi lɔs twɛlv mɛn.

Vestas said urgently, his voice a deep whisper. "The wounded are sorted. We lost twelve men.

ənʌðɝ fɪftin ɑɹ wundəd bʌt kən wɔk ən ɑɹ hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə boʊts. sɪks ɑɹ wundəd tu bædli tə ɡoʊ wɪð ðɛm." vɛstəz hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "θɹi mɛn woʊn læs ði aʊɝ, maɪ lɔɹd."

Another fifteen are wounded but can walk and are heading for the boats. Six are wounded too badly to go with them." Vestas hesitated. "Three men won't last the hour, my Lord."

bɹaɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. "wi muv ɑn."

Bryne gritted his teeth. "We move on."

"aɪ fil ðət peɪn, bɹaɪn," sɪuən sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ɝaʊn ən aɪɪŋ hɪm. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"I feel that pain, Bryne," Siuan said, turning around and eyeing him. "What is it?"

"wi doʊn əv taɪm. ði æmɪɝlɪn - "

"kæn weɪɾ ənʌðɝ moʊmənt. wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"θɹi mɛn," hi sɛd. "aɪ hæv tə liv θɹi ʌv maɪ mɛn tə daɪ."

"Three men," he said. "I have to leave three of my men to die."

"nɑɾ ɪf aɪ hil ðɛm," sɪuən sɛd. "ʃoʊ mi."

"Not if I Heal them," Siuan said. "Show me."

bɹaɪn meɪd noʊ fɝðɝ əbdʒɛkʃən, ðoʊ hi dɪd ɡlæns ət ðə skaɪ. sɛvɹəl ə ðə ɹeɪkən hæd lændəɾ ɛlswɛɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz, veɪɡ blæk ʃeɪps, lɪt baɪ ðə faɪɝz ɪn flɪkɝɪŋ ɔɹənʒ. ðə fliɪŋ sintʃæn wɝ kɑŋɡɹəɡeɪɾɪŋ ət ðɛm.

Bryne made no further objection, though he did glance at the sky. Several of the raken had landed elsewhere in the Tower grounds, vague black shapes, lit by the fires in flickering orange. The fleeing Seanchan were congregating at them.

ðoʊz wɝ ðə ɡɹaʊn əsɔl tʃɹups, hi θɔt. ðeɪ ɹɪli ɑɹ pʊlɪŋ aʊt. ðə ɹeɪɾ ɪz ɛndɪŋ.

Those were the ground assault troops, he thought. They really are pulling out. The raid is ending.

wɪtʃ mɛn ðeɪ wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ə taɪm. əz sun əz ðə sintʃæn lɛft, ðə waɪt taʊɝ wəd stɑɹt tə ɹiɔɹɡənaɪz. ðeɪ niɾəd tə ɹitʃ ɛɡwin! laɪt sɛn ðət ʃi hædn bɪn kæptʃɝd.

Which meant they were running out of time. As soon as the Seanchan left, the White Tower would start to reorganize. They needed to reach Egwene! Light send that she hadn't been captured.

stɪl, ɪf sɪuən wɑntəd tə hil ðə soʊlʒɝz, ðən ɪt wɑz əɹ dɪsɪʒən. hi dʒʌs hoʊp ðət ðiz θɹi laɪvz dɪd nɑɾ ɛn ʌp kɔstɪŋ ðə laɪf ə ði æmɪɝlɪn.

Still, if Siuan wanted to Heal the soldiers, then it was her decision. He just hoped that these three lives did not end up costing the life of the Amyrlin.

vɛstəz hæd sɛt ðə θɹi soʊlʒɝz baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹin, bɪniθ ðə baʊz ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ ʃeɪd tʃɹi. bɹaɪn bɹɔɾ ə skwɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝz, livɪŋ ɡɔɪn tə ɔɹɡənaɪz ðə ɹɛst ə ðə mɛn, ən fɑloʊd sɪuən oʊvɝ tə ðə wundəd. ʃi nɛl bɪsaɪd ðə fɝs mæn. hɝ skɪl ɪn hilɪŋ wɑz nɑt ðə bɛst; ʃid wɔɹn bɹaɪn ə ðɪs əhɛɾ ə taɪm. bʌt pɝhæps ʃi kəd meɪk ðiz θɹi wɛl ɪnʌf ðət ðeɪ wəd sɝvaɪv tə bi dɪskʌvɝɾ ən teɪkən baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Vestas had set the three soldiers by themselves at the side of the green, beneath the boughs of a large shade tree. Bryne brought a squad of soldiers, leaving Gawyn to organize the rest of the men, and followed Siuan over to the wounded. She knelt beside the first man. Her skill in Healing was not the best; she'd warned Bryne of this ahead of time. But perhaps she could make these three well enough that they would survive to be discovered and taken by the White Tower.

ʃi wɝkt kwɪkli, ən bɹaɪn noʊɾəst ðət ʃid dʌn hɝsɛlf ən ɪndʒʌstɪs. ʃi sim tə də ə kɹɛɾətəbəl dʒɑb wɪð ðə hilɪŋ. stɪl, ɪt tʊk taɪm. hi skæn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, filɪŋ ɪz æŋzaɪəɾi ɹaɪz.

She worked quickly, and Bryne noticed that she'd done herself an injustice. She seemed to do a creditable job with the Healing. Still, it took time. He scanned the courtyard, feeling his anxiety rise.

ðoʊ blæsts wɝ stɪl biɪŋ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɑn ði ʌpɝ flɔɹz, ðə loʊɝ flɔɹz ən ɡɹaʊnz wɝ saɪlənt. ði oʊnli saʊnz nɪɹbaɪ wɝ ðoʊz ə ðə ɡɹoʊnɪŋ wundəɾ ən ðə kɹæklɪŋ ə fleɪmz.

Though blasts were still being exchanged on the upper floors, the lower floors and grounds were silent. The only sounds nearby were those of the groaning wounded and the crackling of flames.

laɪt, hi θɔt, sɝveɪɪŋ ðə ɹʌbəl, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz aɪz oʊvɝ ðə taʊɝz beɪs. ði ist wɪŋz ɹuf ən fɑɹ wɔl hæd bɪn lɛvəld, ən fleɪmz flɪkɝɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə stʃɹʌktʃɝ. ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɑz ə mɛs ə ɹʌbəl ən ɡaʊudʒɪz. smoʊk hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, pʌnʒənt ən θɪk. wəd ði oʊɡiɝ bi wɪlɪŋ tə ɹɪtɝn ən ɹibɪl ðɪs mæɡnɪfəsən stʃɹʌktʃɝ? wəɾ ɪɾ ɛvɝ bi ðə seɪm əɡɛn, əɹ hæɾ ə simɪŋli ɪtɝnəl mɑnjəmən fɔlən ðɪs ivnɪŋ? wɑz i pɹaʊɾ əɹ ɡɹiv tə hæv wɪtnəst ɪt?

Light, he thought, surveying the rubble, running his eyes over the Tower's base. The east wing's roof and far wall had been leveled, and flames flickered inside the structure. The courtyard was a mess of rubble and gouges. Smoke hung in the air, pungent and thick. Would the Ogier be willing to return and rebuild this magnificent structure? Would it ever be the same again, or had a seemingly eternal monument fallen this evening? Was he proud or grieved to have witnessed it?

ə ʃædoʊ muvd ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɹi.

A shadow moved in the darkness beside the tree.

bɹaɪn muvd wɪθaʊt θɔt. θɹi θɪŋz ɪn ɪm mɪkst: jɪɹz ə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə sɔɹd, ə laɪftaɪm ə pɹæktəs bæɾəlfild ɹiflɛksəz ən ə nu bɑnd-ɛnhænst əwɛɹnəs. ɔl keɪm təɡɛðɝ ɪn wʌn moʊʃən. hɪz sɔɹd wɑz aʊɾ ɪn ə hɑɹtbit, ən i pɝfɔɹm blæklənsəz læst stʃɹaɪk, slæmɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd stʃɹeɪɾ ɪndə ðə nɛk ə ðə dɑɹk fɪɡjɝ.

Bryne moved without thought. Three things in him mixed: years of training with the sword, a lifetime of practiced battlefield reflexes and a new bond-enhanced awareness. All came together in one motion. His sword was out in a heartbeat, and he performed Blacklance's Last Strike, slamming his sword straight into the neck of the dark figure.

ɔl wɑz stɪl. sɪuən, ʃɑkt, lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə mæn ʃi wɑz hilɪŋ. bɹaɪnz sɔɹɾ ɪkstɛndəd dɝɛkli oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən ɪndə ðə nɛk ʌv ə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝ ɪn pjʊɹ blæk ɑɹmɝ. ðə mæn saɪlənli dʒɹɑpt ə wɪkɪdli bɑɹbd ʃɔɹtsɔɝd slæðɝd wɪð ə vɪskəs lɪkwəd. twɪtʃɪŋ, hi ɹitʃt fəɹ bɹaɪnz sɔɹd, əz ɪf tə pʊʃ ɪt fɹi. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɡɹɪp bɹaɪnz ɑɹm fəɹ ə moʊmənt.

All was still. Siuan, shocked, looked up from the man she was Healing. Bryne's sword extended directly over her shoulder and into the neck of a Seanchan soldier in pure black armor. The man silently dropped a wickedly barbed shortsword slathered with a viscous liquid. Twitching, he reached for Bryne's sword, as if to push it free. His fingers gripped Bryne's arm for a moment.

ðən ðə mæn slɪd bækwɝɾ ɔf ə bɹaɪnz bleɪɾ ən tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi spæzmd wʌns, wɪspɝɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ dɪstɪŋk dɪspaɪt ðə bʌbəlɪŋ ə hɪz bliɾɪŋ θɹoʊt. "mɛɹəθ . . . deɪmeɪn . . ."

Then the man slid backward off of Bryne's blade and to the ground. He spasmed once, whispering something distinct despite the bubbling of his bleeding throat. "Marath . . . damane . . ."

"laɪt bɝn mi!" sɪuən bɹiðd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə hɝ bɹɛst. "wʌt wɑz ðæt?"

"Light burn me!" Siuan breathed, raising a hand to her breast. "What was that?"

"hi wɑzn dʒɹɛs laɪk ði ʌðɝz," bɹaɪn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "ði ɑɹmɝ ɪz dɪfɹənt.

"He wasn't dressed like the others," Bryne said, shaking his head. "The armor is different.

əsæsən ə səm sɔɹt."

Assassin of some sort."

"laɪt," sɪuən sɛd. "aɪ dɪdn ivən si hɪm! hi ɔlmoʊst sim pɑɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹknəs ɪtsɛlf!"

"Light," Siuan said. "I didn't even see him! He almost seemed part of the darkness itself!"

əsæsənz. ðeɪ ɔlweɪz sim tə lʊk ðə seɪm, ɹəɡɑɹdləs ə ðə kʌltʃɝ. bɹaɪn ʃiðd ɪz sɔɹd. ðət wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm hiɾ ɛvɝ juz blæklənsəz læst stʃɹaɪk ɪn kɑmbæt. ɪt wɑz ə sɪmpəl fɔɹm, ɪntɛndəd fəɹ oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ: spid. dʒɹɔ ðə sɔɹɾ ən stʃɹaɪk ɪndə ðə nɛk ɪn wʌn fluəd moʊʃən.

Assassins. They always seemed to look the same, regardless of the culture. Bryne sheathed his sword. That was the first time he'd ever used Blacklance's Last Strike in combat. It was a simple form, intended for only one thing: speed. Draw the sword and strike into the neck in one fluid motion.

ɪf jə mɪst, jə juʒəwəli daɪd.

If you missed, you usually died.

"ju seɪv maɪ laɪf," sɪuən sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət bɹaɪn. hɝ feɪs wɑz moʊsli ʃæɾoʊd. "baɪ ðə siz ət mɪdnaɪt," ʃi sɛd, "ðə blæstəd ɡɝl wɑz ɹaɪt."

"You saved my life," Siuan said, looking up at Bryne. Her face was mostly shadowed. "By the seas at midnight," she said, "the blasted girl was right."

"hu?" bɹaɪn æskt, wɛɹəli skænɪŋ ðə dɑɹknəs fəɹ mɔɹ əsæsənz. hi weɪv kɝtli, ən ɪz mɛn ʃipɪʃli oʊpən ðɛɹ læntɝnz fɝðɝ. ði əsæsənz ətæk hæd kʌm soʊ kwɪkli ðət ðeɪ hæd bɛɹli muvd. ɪf bɹaɪn hædn hæd ðə spiɾ ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd. . . .

"Who?" Bryne asked, warily scanning the darkness for more assassins. He waved curtly, and his men sheepishly opened their lanterns further. The assassin's attack had come so quickly that they had barely moved. If Bryne hadn't had the speed of a Warder bond. . . .

"mɪn," sɪuən sɛd, saʊndɪŋ taɪɝd. ðoʊz hilɪŋz sim tə hæv teɪkən ə lɑɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ. "ʃi sɛɾ aɪ hæd tə steɪ nɪɹ ju." ʃi pɔzd. "ɪf jə hædn kʌm tənaɪt, aɪ wəɾ əv daɪd."

"Min," Siuan said, sounding tired. Those Healings seemed to have taken a lot out of her. "She said I had to stay near you." She paused. "If you hadn't come tonight, I would have died."

"wɛl," bɹaɪn sɛd, "aɪ æm jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ. aɪ səspɛkt ɪt woʊn bi ði oʊnli taɪm aɪ seɪv ju." waɪ hæɾ ɪt ɡɹoʊn soʊ wɔɹm ɔl ʌv ə sʌɾən?

"Well," Bryne said, "I am your Warder. I suspect it won't be the only time I save you." Why had it grown so warm all of a sudden?

"jɛs," sɪuən sɛd, stændɪŋ ʌp. "bʌt ðɪs ɪz dɪfɹənt. mɪn sɛɾ aɪd daɪ, ən . . . noʊ, weɪt. ðæts nɑt wʌt mɪn sɛɾ ɪɡzækli. ʃi sɛd ðəɾ ɪf aɪ dɪdn steɪ kloʊs tə ju, wid boʊθ daɪ."

"Yes," Siuan said, standing up. "But this is different. Min said I'd die, and . . . No, wait. That's not what Min said exactly. She said that if I didn't stay close to you, we'd both die."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə - " bɹaɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd hɝ.

"What are you - " Bryne said, turning toward her.

"hʌʃ!" sɪuən sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn əɹ hænz. hi fɛlt ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pɹɪklɪŋ sɛnseɪʃən. wɑz ʃi juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɑn hɪm? wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn? hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət ʃɑk, laɪk aɪs ɪn ðə veɪnz! ʃi wɑz hilɪŋ hɪm! bʌt waɪ? hi wɑznt wundəd.

"Hush!" Siuan said, taking his head in her hands. He felt a strange prickling sensation. Was she using the Power on him? What was going on? He recognized that shock, like ice in the veins! She was Healing him! But why? He wasn't wounded.

sɪuən tʊk əɹ hænz ɔf ɪz feɪs, ðən tiɾɝd slaɪtli wɪð ə sʌɾən lʊk ʌv ɪɡzɔstʃən. hi ɡɹæb hɝ, tə hɛlp stɛɾi hɝ, bʌt ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən ɹaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf. "hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd, ɡɹæbɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ɑɹm, twɪstɪŋ ɪt soʊ ðət ðə ɹɪst wɑz vɪzəbəl. ðɛɹ, pɹɛst ɪndə hɪz skɪn, wɑz ə taɪni blæk pɪn. ʃi jæŋkt ɪt fɹi. bɹaɪn fɛlt ə tʃɪl toʊɾəli ʌnɹɪleɪɾɪd tə ðə hilɪŋ.

Siuan took her hands off his face, then teetered slightly with a sudden look of exhaustion. He grabbed her, to help steady her, but she shook her head and righted herself. "Here," she said, grabbing his sword arm, twisting it so that the wrist was visible. There, pressed into his skin, was a tiny black pin. She yanked it free. Bryne felt a chill totally unrelated to the Healing.

"pɔɪzənd?" hi æskt, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə dɛd mæn. "wɛn i ɹitʃt fəɹ maɪ ɑɹm, ɪt wɑzn ə sɪmpəl dɛθ spæzəm."

"Poisoned?" he asked, glancing at the dead man. "When he reached for my arm, it wasn't a simple death spasm."

"pɹɑbli hæɾ ə nʌmɪŋ eɪdʒən ɑn ɪt," sɪuən mʌɾɝd æŋɡɹəli, lɛɾɪŋ ɪm hɛlp əɹ sɪt daʊn. ʃi tɔs ðə pɪn əsaɪɾ ən ɪt sʌɾənli bɝst ɪndə fleɪmz, ðə pɔɪzən ɪvæpɝeɪɾɪŋ bɪniθ ðə hiɾ ə hɝ tʃænəlɪŋ.

"Probably had a numbing agent on it," Siuan muttered angrily, letting him help her sit down. She tossed the pin aside and it suddenly burst into flames, the poison evaporating beneath the heat of her channeling.

bɹaɪn ɹæn ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. hɪz bɹaʊ wɑz dæmp. "dɪd jə . . . hil ɪt?"

Bryne ran a hand through his hair. His brow was damp. "Did you . . . Heal it?"

sɪuən nɑɾəd. "ɪt wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli izi; ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl ɪn jəɹ sɪstəm. ɪt wʊɾə kɪl jə ɛniweɪ. jəl əv tə θæŋk mɪn nɛks taɪm jə si hɝ, bɹaɪn. ʃi dʒʌst seɪv boʊθ ʌv əɹ laɪvz."

Siuan nodded. "It was surprisingly easy; there was only a little in your system. It would have killed you anyway. You'll have to thank Min next time you see her, Bryne. She just saved both of our lives."

"bʌɾ aɪ wʊdn əv bɪn pɔɪzən ɪf aɪ hædn kʌm!"

"But I wouldn't have been poisoned if I hadn't come!"

"doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə əplaɪ lɑdʒɪk tə ə vjuɪŋ əɹ fɔɹtɛlɪŋ laɪk ðɪs," sɪuən sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "jɔɹ əlaɪv. aɪm əlaɪv. aɪ sədʒɛst wi liv ɪɾ ət ðæt. jə fil ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf tə kip ɡoʊɪŋ?"

"Don't try to apply logic to a viewing or Foretelling like this," Siuan said, grimacing. "You're alive. I'm alive. I suggest we leave it at that. You feel good enough to keep going?"

"dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ?" bɹaɪn sɛd. "aɪm nɑɾ əbaʊt tə lɛt jə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪθaʊt mi."

"Does it matter?" Bryne said. "I'm not about to let you go on without me."

"lɛts muv, ðɛn," sɪuən sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ ən klaɪmɪŋ tə hɝ fit. ðət ɹɛs hædn bɪn nɪɹli lɔŋ ɪnʌf, bʌɾ i dɪdn tʃælənʒ hɝ. "ðiz θɹi soʊlʒɝz ə jʊɹz wɪl sɝvaɪv ðə naɪt. aɪv dʌn wʌɾ aɪ kən fəɹ ðɛm."

"Let's move, then," Siuan said, taking a deep breath and climbing to her feet. That rest hadn't been nearly long enough, but he didn't challenge her. "These three soldiers of yours will survive the night. I've done what I can for them."

ɛɡwin sæt, ɪɡzɔstəd, ɑn ə paɪl ə ɹʌbəl, stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə hoʊl ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wɑtʃɪŋ faɪɝz bɝnɪŋ bɪloʊ. fɪɡjɝz muvd əbaʊt ðɛm, ən wʌn baɪ wʌn, ðə faɪɝz wɪŋkt aʊt. huɛvɝ hæd bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ ðə ɹɪzɪstəns wɑz kwɪk-maɪndəɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹilaɪz ðət ðə faɪɝz kəd pɹuv əz deɪnʒɝəs əz ðə sintʃæn. bʌɾ ə fju sɪstɝz wivɪŋ ɛɹ əɹ wɔɾɝ kəd meɪk ʃɔɹt wɝk ə ðə fleɪmz, pɹəzɝvɪŋ ðə taʊɝ. wʌt wɑz lɛft ʌv ɪt.

Egwene sat, exhausted, on a pile of rubble, staring out of the hole in the White Tower, watching fires burning below. Figures moved about them, and one by one, the fires winked out. Whoever had been running the resistance was quick-minded enough to realize that the fires could prove as dangerous as the Seanchan. But a few sisters weaving Air or Water could make short work of the flames, preserving the Tower. What was left of it.

ɛɡwin kloʊzd əɹ aɪz ən leɪ bæk, ɹɛstɪŋ əɡɛns ðə fɹæɡməns ʌv ə wɔl, filɪŋ ðə fɹɛʃ bɹiz bloʊ əkɹɔs hɝ. ðə sintʃæn wɝ ɡɔn, ðə læs tɔɹeɪkən vænɪʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə naɪt. ðət moʊmənt, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪt fli, wɑz ðə moʊmənt wən ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz haʊ hɑɹd ʃid tæks hɝsɛlf ən ðə pʊɹ nɑvəsɪz ʃid bɪn dʒɹɔɪŋ θɹu. ʃid ɹilist əm wɪð ɔɹɾɝz tə ɡoʊ dɝɛkli tə slip.

Egwene closed her eyes and lay back, resting against the fragments of a wall, feeling the fresh breeze blow across her. The Seanchan were gone, the last to'raken vanishing into the night. That moment, watching it flee, was the moment when Egwene realized how hard she'd taxed herself and the poor novices she'd been drawing through. She'd released them with orders to go directly to sleep.

ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ʃid ɡæðɝd wɝ kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ wundəɾ əɹ wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðə faɪɝz ɑn ði ʌpɝ lɛvəlz.

The other women she'd gathered were caring for wounded or working on the fires on the upper levels.

ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə hɛlp. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ dɪd, ət list. ə slɪvɝ. bʌt laɪt, ʃi wɑz taɪɝd! ʃi kʊdn tʃænəl ənʌðɝ tʃɹɪkəl, nɑɾ ivən juzɪŋ ðə sɑŋɡɹil. ʃid pʊʃt ðə lɪməts ʌv wʌt ʃi kəd mænədʒ. bʌt ʃi wɑz soʊ wɔɹn aʊt naʊ ðət ʃi wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd.

Egwene wanted to help. A part of her did, at least. A sliver. But Light, she was tired! She couldn't channel another trickle, not even using the sa'angreal. She'd pushed the limits of what she could manage. But she was so worn out now that she wouldn't be able to embrace the Source if she tried.

ʃid fɔt. ʃid bɪn ɡlɔɹiəs ən dɪstʃɹʌktɪv, ði æmɪɝlɪn ə dʒʌdʒmən ən fjʊɹi, ɡɹin ədʒɑ tə ðə kɔɹ. ən stɪl, ðə taʊɝ hæd bɝnd. ən stɪl, mɔɹ tɔɹeɪkən hæɾ ɪskeɪp ðən hæd fɔlən.

She'd fought. She'd been glorious and destructive, the Amyrlin of judgment and fury, Green Ajah to the core. And still, the Tower had burned. And still, more to'raken had escaped than had fallen.

ðə kaʊn ʌv wundəɾ əmʌŋ ðoʊz ʃid ɡæðɝd wɑz sʌmwʌɾ ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ. oʊnli θɹi nɑvəsɪz ən wʌn ɛɛs sədaɪ dɛd, waɪl ðeɪd ɡæðɝd tɛn deɪmeɪn ən kɪl dʌzənz ə soʊlʒɝz. bʌt wʌɾ ə ði ʌðɝ flɔɹz? ðə waɪt taʊɝ wəd nɑt kʌm aʊɾ əhɛɾ ɪn ðɪs bæɾəl.

The count of wounded among those she'd gathered was somewhat encouraging. Only three novices and one Aes Sedai dead, while they'd gathered ten damane and killed dozens of soldiers. But what of the other floors? The White Tower would not come out ahead in this battle.

ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz bɹoʊkən, fɪzɪkəli naʊ əz wɛl əz spɪɹɪtʃəwəli. ðeɪd niɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ liɾɝ tə ɹibɪld. ðə nɛks fju deɪz wəd bi pɪvəɾəl. ɪt meɪɾ əɹ mɔɹ ðən ɪɡzɔstəd tə kənsɪɾɝ ðə wɝk ʃid nid tə du.

The White Tower was broken, physically now as well as spiritually. They'd need a strong leader to rebuild. The next few days would be pivotal. It made her more than exhausted to consider the work she'd need to do.

ʃi hæd pɹətɛktəd mɛni. ʃi hæd ɹɪzɪstɪɾ ən fɔt. bʌt ðɪs deɪ wəd stɪl mɑɹk wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst dɪzæstɝz ɪn ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

She had protected many. She had resisted and fought. But this day would still mark one of the greatest disasters in the history of the Aes Sedai.

kæn θɪŋk ə ðæt, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf. hæv tə foʊkəs ɑn wʌt tə də tə fɪks θɪŋz. . . .

Can't think of that, she told herself. Have to focus on what to do to fix things. . . .

ʃi wəd ɡɛɾ ʌp sun. ʃi wəd lɛd ðə nɑvəsɪz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ðiz ʌpɝ flɔɹz əz ðeɪ klin ʌp ən əsɛs ðə dæmədʒ. ʃi wəd bi stʃɹɔŋ ən keɪpəbəl. ði ʌðɝz wəd bi tɛmptəd tə fɔl ɪndə dɪspɛɹ, ən ʃi niɾəd tə bi pɑzəɾɪv. fəɹ ðɛm.

She would get up soon. She would lead the novices and Aes Sedai on these upper floors as they cleaned up and assessed the damage. She would be strong and capable. The others would be tempted to fall into despair, and she needed to be positive. For them.

bʌt ʃi kəd teɪk ə fju mɪnəts. ʃi dʒʌs niɾəd tə ɹɛs fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl. . . .

But she could take a few minutes. She just needed to rest for a little while. . . .

ʃi bɛɹli noʊɾəst wən sʌmwʌn pɪkt əɹ ʌp. ʃi taɪɹədli oʊpən əɹ aɪz, ən - ðoʊ nʌm ə maɪnd - wɑz əstɑnɪʃt tə faɪn ðət ʃi wɑz biɪŋ kæɹid baɪ ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd. hɪz fɔɹhɛd wɑz smɪɹd wɪð kɹʌsti dʒɹaɪd blʌd, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs wɑz dɪtɝmənd. "aɪv ɡɑt ju, ɛɡwin," hi sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ daʊn. "aɪl pɹətɛk ju."

She barely noticed when someone picked her up. She tiredly opened her eyes, and - though numb of mind - was astonished to find that she was being carried by Gawyn Trakand. His forehead was smeared with crusty dried blood, but his face was determined. "I've got you, Egwene," he said, glancing down. "I'll protect you."

oʊ, ʃi θɔt, kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz əɡɛn. ɡʊd. sətʃ ə plɛzən dʒɹim. ʃi smaɪld.

Oh, she thought, closing her eyes again. Good. Such a pleasant dream. She smiled.

weɪt. noʊ. ðət wɑzn ɹaɪt. ʃi wɑzn səpoʊz tə bi livɪŋ ðə taʊɝ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə vɔɪs kəmpleɪnt, bʌt ʃi kəd bɛɹli mʌmbəl.

Wait. No. That wasn't right. She wasn't supposed to be leaving the Tower. She tried to voice complaint, but she could barely mumble.

"fɪʃ ɡʌts," ʃi hɝd sɪuən sɑntʃ seɪ. "wʌt dɪd ðeɪ də tə hɝ?"

"Fish guts," she heard Siuan Sanche say. "What did they do to her?"

"ɪz ʃi wundəd?" ənʌðɝ vɔɪs. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn.

"Is she wounded?" another voice. Gareth Bryne.

noʊ, ɛɡwin θɔt nʌmbli. noʊ, juv tə lemi ɡoʊ. aɪ kæn liv. nɑt naʊ. . . .

No, Egwene thought numbly. No, you have to let me go. I can't leave. Not now. . . .

"ðeɪ dʒʌs lɛft əɹ ðɛɹ, sɪuən," ɡɔɪn sɛd. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz soʊ naɪs tə hɪɹ. "dɪfɛnsləs ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ! ɛniwʌn cʊɾə kʌm əpɑn əɹ laɪk ðæt. wʌɾ ɪf ðə sintʃæn hæd dɪskʌvɝd hɝ?"

"They just left her there, Siuan," Gawyn said. His voice was so nice to hear. "Defenseless in the hallway! Anyone could have come upon her like that. What if the Seanchan had discovered her?"

aɪ dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðɛm, ʃi θɔt wɪð ə smaɪl, θɔts slɪpɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. aɪ wɑz ə bɝnɪŋ wɔɹiɝ, ə hɪɹoʊ kɔl baɪ ðə hɔɹn. ðeɪ woʊn dɛɹ feɪs mi əɡɛn. ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛl əslip, bʌt biɪŋ dʒɑsəl baɪ ɡɔɪnz stɛps kɛpt əɹ əweɪk. bɛɹli.

I destroyed them, she thought with a smile, thoughts slipping away from her. I was a burning warrior, a hero called by the Horn. They won't dare face me again. She almost fell asleep, but being jostled by Gawyn's steps kept her awake. Barely.

"hoʊ!" ʃi dɪstənli hɝd sɪuənz vɔɪs. "wʌts ðɪs? laɪt, ɛɡwin! wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡɛt ðɪs?

"Ho!" She distantly heard Siuan's voice. "What's this? Light, Egwene! Where did you get this?

ðɪs ɪz ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wʌn ɪn ðə taʊɝ!"

This is the most powerful one in the Tower!"

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt, sɪuən?" bɹaɪnz vɔɪs æskt.

"What is it, Siuan?" Bryne's voice asked.

"aʊɝ weɪ aʊt," sɪuən sɛd dɪstənli. ɛɡwin sɛnst sʌmθɪŋ. tʃænəlɪŋ. paʊɝfəl tʃænəlɪŋ.

"Our way out," Siuan said distantly. Egwene sensed something. Channeling. Powerful channeling.

"ju æskt əbaʊt snikɪŋ bæk aʊt wɪð ɔl ði æktɪvəɾi ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd? wɛl, wɪð ðɪs, aɪm stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ. lɛts ɡoʊ kəlɛk ðoʊz soʊlʒɝz wɪð ðə boʊts ən hɑp bæk tə kæmp."

"You asked about sneaking back out with all the activity in the courtyard? Well, with this, I'm strong enough for Traveling. Let's go collect those soldiers with the boats and hop back to camp."

noʊ! ɛɡwin θɔt, klɔɪŋ θɹu hɝ dʒɹaʊzinəs, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ aɪz oʊpən. aɪm wɪnɪŋ, doʊn jə si? ɪf aɪ ɔfɝ liɾɝʃɪp naʊ, wən ðə ɹʌbəl ɪz biɪŋ klɪɹd, ðəl si mi əz æmɪɝlɪn fəɹ sɝɾən! aɪ hæv tə steɪ! aɪ hæv tə -  ɡɔɪn kæɹiɾ əɹ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, livɪŋ ðə hɔlweɪz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ bɪhaɪnd.

No! Egwene thought, clawing through her drowsiness, forcing her eyes open. I'm winning, don't you see? If I offer leadership now, when the rubble is being cleared, they'll see me as Amyrlin for certain! I have to stay! I have to -  Gawyn carried her through the gateway, leaving the hallways of the White Tower behind.

sɹɪn faɪnəli lɛt hɝsɛlf sɪt. ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ ɹum ðət wɑz əɹ sɛntɝ ʌv ɑpɝeɪʃənz hæɾ ɔlsoʊ bɪkʌm ə ɹum fəɹ sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ ən hilɪŋ ðə wundəd. jɛloʊ ən bɹaʊn sɪstɝz muv daʊn ðə laɪnz ə soʊlʒɝz, sɝvəns, ən ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ðə wɝs keɪsəz fɝst. ðəɹ wɝ ə fɹaɪtfəl nʌmbɝ ə dɛd, ɪnkluɾɪŋ oʊvɝ twɛnti ɛɛs sədaɪ soʊ fɑɹ. bʌt ðə sintʃæn hæd wɪθdʒɹɔn, əz sɹɪn hæd pɹɪdɪktɪd. θæŋk ðə laɪt fəɹ ðæt.

Saerin finally let herself sit. The gathering room that was her center of operations had also become a room for separating and Healing the wounded. Yellow and Brown sisters moved down the lines of soldiers, servants, and other sisters, focusing on the worst cases first. There were a frightful number of dead, including over twenty Aes Sedai so far. But the Seanchan had withdrawn, as Saerin had predicted. Thank the light for that.

sɹɪn hɝsɛlf sæɾ ət ðə fɑɹ nɔɹθwɛstɝn kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum, bɪniθ ə faɪn peɪntɪŋ ə tiɹ ɪn spɹɪŋ, pɝtʃt ɑn ə ʃɔɹt stul ən æksɛptɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts əz ðeɪ keɪm. ðə wundəd ɡɹoʊn ən ðə ɹum smɛld ə blʌɾ ən ə hilɔl, wɪtʃ wɑz juzd ɑn ðoʊz huz wunz dɪdn dɪmæn ɪmiɾiət hilɪŋ. ðə ɹum ɔlsoʊ smɛld ə smoʊk. ðət wɑz ɛvɝ-pɹɛzən tənaɪt. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz əpɹoʊtʃt hɝ, hændɪŋ ɪn ɹɪpɔɹts ə dæmədʒ ən kæʒəwəltiz. sɹɪn dɪdnt wɑnə ɹid fɝðɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən lɪsnɪŋ tə ðoʊz ɡɹoʊnz. wɛɹ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt wɑz ɪleɪɾə?

Saerin herself sat at the far northwestern corner of the room, beneath a fine painting of Tear in spring, perched on a short stool and accepting reports as they came. The wounded groaned and the room smelled of blood and of healall, which was used on those whose wounds didn't demand immediate Healing. The room also smelled of smoke. That was ever-present tonight. More and more soldiers approached her, handing in reports of damage and casualties. Saerin didn't want to read further, but it was better than listening to those groans. Where under the Light was Elaida?

noʊbɑdi hæd sin ɛniθɪŋ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn dʊɹɪŋ ðə bæɾəl, bʌt mʌtʃ ə ði ʌpɝ taʊɝ hæd bɪn kʌɾ ɔf fɹəm ðə loʊɝ pɔɹʃənz. hoʊpfəli, ði æmɪɝlɪn ən ðə hɔl kəd bi ɡæðɝd sun tə pɹizɛn ə stʃɹɔŋ liɾɝʃɪp ɪn ðə kɹaɪsəs.

Nobody had seen anything of the Amyrlin during the battle, but much of the upper Tower had been cut off from the lower portions. Hopefully, the Amyrlin and the Hall could be gathered soon to present a strong leadership in the crisis.

sɹɪn æksɛptɪɾ ənʌðɝ ɹipɔɹt, ðən ɹeɪzd əɹ aɪbɹaʊz ət wʌɾ ɪt sɛd. oʊnli θɹi nɑvəsɪz ɪn ɛɡwinz ɡɹup ʌv oʊvɝ sɪksti hæd daɪd? ən oʊnli wʌn sɪstɝ aʊɾ ə səm fɔɹɾi ʃi hæd ɡæðɝd? tɛn sintʃæn tʃænlɝz kæptʃɝd, oʊvɝ θɝɾi ɹeɪkən bloʊn fɹəm ði ɛɹ? laɪt! ðət meɪd sɹɪnz oʊn ɛfɝts sim daʊnɹaɪɾ æmətɝ baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən. ən ðɪs wɑz ðə wʊmən ɪleɪɾə kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪnsɪst wɑz sɪmpli ə nɑvəs?

Saerin accepted another report, then raised her eyebrows at what it said. Only three novices in Egwene's group of over sixty had died? And only one sister out of some forty she had gathered? Ten Seanchan channelers captured, over thirty raken blown from the air? Light! That made Saerin's own efforts seem downright amateur by comparison. And this was the woman Elaida kept trying to insist was simply a novice?

"sɹɪn sədaɪ?" ə mænz vɔɪs æskt.

"Saerin Sedai?" a man's voice asked.

"m?" ʃi æskt, dɪstʃɹæktəd.

Saerin looked up, realizing that the voice belonged to Captain Chubain. He had his hand on the shoulder of a young Arafellin Accepted with blue eyes and a plump round face. What was her name?

Mair, that was it. The poor child looked ragged. Her face sported a number of cuts and some scrapes that would likely bruise. Her Accepted dress was ripped on the sleeve and shoulder.

ðə ɡɝl stɑɹɾəd kɹaɪɪŋ. "ði ɪntaɪɝ wɔl bɝst ɪn, sɹɪn sədaɪ. ðə ɹʌbəl kʌvɝd mi; aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz dɛd. aɪ kʊdn də ɛniθɪŋ! aɪm sɑɹi!"

The girl started crying. "The entire wall burst in, Saerin Sedai. The rubble covered me; I think they thought I was dead. I couldn't do anything! I'm sorry!"

laɪɾ ɪntɝsid! sɹɪn θɔt. ʃi kæn bi seɪɪŋ wʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ʃi ɪz. kən ʃi?

Light intercede! Saerin thought. She can't be saying what I think she is. Can she?

Elaida awoke to a very odd sensation. Why was her bed moving? Rippling, undulating. So rhythmic. And that wind! Had Carlya left the window open? If so, the maid would be beaten. She'd been warned. She'd been -  This was not her bed. Elaida opened her eyes and found herself looking down at a dark landscape hundreds of feet below. She was tied to the back of some strange beast. She couldn't move. Why couldn't she move? She reached for the Source, then felt a sudden, sharp pain, as though she had suddenly been beaten on every inch of her body with a thousand rods.

ʃi ɹitʃt ʌp, deɪzd, filɪŋ ðə kɑlɝ əɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. ðəɹ wɑz ə dɑɹk fɪɡjɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sæɾəl nɛks tə hɝ; noʊ læntɝnz lɪt ðə wʊmənz feɪs, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə kəd fil əɹ sʌmhaʊ. ɪleɪɾə kəd dʒʌs bɛɹli ɹɪmɛmbɝ spɛndɪŋ taɪm dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, taɪd tə ə ɹoʊp, əz ʃi fɛl ɪn ən aʊɾ ə kɑnʃəsnəs. wən hæd ʃi bɪn pʊld ʌp? wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ?

She reached up, dazed, feeling the collar at her throat. There was a dark figure riding in the saddle next to her; no lanterns lit the woman's face, but Elaida could feel her somehow. Elaida could just barely remember spending time dangling in the air, tied to a rope, as she fell in and out of consciousness. When had she been pulled up? What was happening?

ə vɔɪs wɪspɝd fɹəm ðə naɪt. "aɪ ʃæl fɝɡɪv ðət lɪɾəl mɪsteɪk. juv bɪn mɛɹəθdəmeɪn fəɹ vɛɹi lɔŋ, ən bæd hæbəts ɑɹ tə bi ɪkspɛktəd. bʌt jəl nɑt ɹitʃ fəɹ ðə sɔɹs əɡɛn wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən. dʒju ʌndɝstænd?"

A voice whispered from the night. "I shall forgive that little mistake. You have been marath'damane for very long, and bad habits are to be expected. But you will not reach for the Source again without permission. Do you understand?"

"ɹilis mi!" ɪleɪɾə bɛloʊd.

"Release me!" Elaida bellowed.

ðə peɪn ɹɪtɝn tɛnfoʊld, ən ɪleɪɾə ɹɛtʃt ət ði ɪntɛnsəɾi ʌv ɪt. hɝ baɪl ən sɪk-ʌp fɛl oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bist ən dʒɹɑp fɑɹ tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪloʊ.

The pain returned tenfold, and Elaida retched at the intensity of it. Her bile and sick-up fell over the side of the beast and dropped far to the ground below.

"naʊ, naʊ," ðə vɔɪs sɛd, peɪʃənt, laɪk ə wʊmən spikɪŋ tə ə vɛɹi jʌŋ tʃaɪld. "ju mʌs lɝn. jəɹ neɪm ɪz sʌfə. ən sʌfə wɪl bi ə ɡʊd deɪmeɪn. jɛs ʃi wɪl. ə vɛɹi, vɛɹi ɡʊd deɪmeɪn."

"Now, now," the voice said, patient, like a woman speaking to a very young child. "You must learn. Your name is Suffa. And Suffa will be a good damane. Yes she will. A very, very good damane."

ɪleɪɾə skɹimd əɡɛn, ən ðɪs taɪm, ʃi dɪdn stɑp wən ðə peɪn keɪm. ʃi dʒʌs kɛp skɹimɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ði ənkɛɹɪŋ naɪt.

Elaida screamed again, and this time, she didn't stop when the pain came. She just kept screaming out into the uncaring night.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾitu

CHAPTER 42

bɪfɔɹ ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ wi doʊnt noʊ ðə neɪmz ə ðə wɪmən u wɝ ɪn ɡɹeɪndəlz pæləs, luz θɝɪn sɛd. wi kæn æɾ əm tə ðə lɪst.

Before the Stone of Tear We don't know the names of the women who were in Graendal's palace, Lews Therin said. We can't add them to the list.

ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə mædmæn. ðət pɹuvd ɪmpɑsəbəl. luz θɝɪn kəntɪnjud.

Rand tried to ignore the madman. That proved impossible. Lews Therin continued.

haʊ kən wi kəntɪnju ðə lɪst ɪf wi doʊnt noʊ ðə neɪmz! ɪn wɔɹ, wi sɔɾ aʊt ðə meɪɾənz u hæd fɔlən. wi faʊn ɛvɹi wʌn! ðə lɪst ɪz flɔd! aɪ kæn kəntɪnju!

It's not your list! Rand growled. It's mine, Lews Therin. MINE!

noʊ! ðə mædmæn spʌɾɝd. hu ɑɹ ju? ɪts maɪn! aɪ meɪɾ ɪt. aɪ kæn kəntɪnju naʊ ðət ðəɹ dɛd. oʊ, laɪt! bɑlfaɪɝ? waɪ dɪd wi juz bɑlfaɪɝ! aɪ pɹɑməs ðəɾ aɪ wəd nɛvɝ də ðəɾ əɡɛn. . . .

No! the madman sputtered. Who are you? It's mine! I made it. I can't continue now that they're dead. Oh, Light! Balefire? Why did we use balefire! I promised that I would never do that again. . . .

ɹænd skwizd ɪz aɪz ʃʌt, hoʊldɪŋ taɪtli tə teɪdeɪʃɝz ɹeɪnz. ðə wɔɹhɔɹs pɪkt ɪz weɪ daʊn ðə stʃɹit; ðə hʊvz hɪt pækt ɝθ, wʌn æftɝ ənʌðɝ.

Rand squeezed his eyes shut, holding tightly to Tai'daishar's reins. The warhorse picked his way down the street; the hooves hit packed earth, one after another.

wʌɾ əv wi bɪkʌm? luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. wɝ gɑnə də ɪɾ əɡɛn, ɑɹənt wi? kɪl əm ɔl. ɛvɹiwʌn wiv lʌvd. əɡɛn, əɡɛn, əɡɛn. . . .

What have we become? Lews Therin whispered. We're going to do it again, aren't we? Kill them all. Everyone we've loved. Again, again, again. . . .

"əɡɛn ən əɡɛn," ɹænd wɪspɝd. "ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ, əz lɔŋ əz ðə wɝl sɝvaɪvz. ðeɪ kɝs mi bɪfɔɹ, swɔɹ ət dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn ən baɪ maɪ neɪm, bʌt ðeɪ lɪvd. wɝ hɪɹ, ɹɛɾi tə faɪt.

"Again and again," Rand whispered. "It doesn't matter, as long as the world survives. They cursed me before, swore at Dragonmount and by my name, but they lived. We're here, ready to fight.

əɡɛn ən əɡɛn."

Again and again."

"ɹænd?" mɪn æskt.

"Rand?" Min asked.

hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz. ʃi ɹoʊɾ əɹ dʌn mɛɹ nɛks tə teɪdeɪʃɝ. hi kʊdn lɛt hɝ, əɹ ɛni ʌv ðɛm, si hɪm slɪpɪŋ. ðeɪ mʌsnt noʊ haʊ kloʊs i wɑz tə kəlæpsɪŋ.

He opened his eyes. She rode her dun mare next to Tai'daishar. He couldn't let her, or any of them, see him slipping. They mustn't know how close he was to collapsing.

soʊ mɛni neɪmz wi doʊnt noʊ, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. soʊ mɛni dɛd baɪ əɹ hænd.

So many names we don't know, Lews Therin whispered. So many dead by our hand.

ən ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

And it was just the beginning.

"aɪ æm wɛl, mɪn," hi sɛd. "aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ."

"I am well, Min," he said. "I was thinking."

"About the people?" Min asked. The wooden walks of Bandar Eban were filled with people.

ɹænd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɔ ðə kʌlɝz ə ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ; hi sɔ haʊ wɔɹn ðət kloʊðɪŋ wɑz. hi sɔ ðə ɹɪps ɪn ðə mæɡnɪfəsən fæbɹɪk, ðə θɹɛdbɛɹ pætʃəz, ðə dɝɾ ən ðə steɪnz. vɝtʃuəli ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən wɑz ə ɹɛfjʊdʒi ʌv wʌn sɔɹɾ əɹ ənʌðɝ. ðeɪ wɑtʃt ɪm wɪð hɔntəɾ aɪz.

Rand no longer saw the colors of their clothing; he saw how worn that clothing was. He saw the rips in the magnificent fabric, the threadbare patches, the dirt and the stains. Virtually everyone in Bandar Eban was a refugee of one sort or another. They watched him with haunted eyes.

itʃ taɪm hid kɑŋkɝɾ ə kɪŋdəm bɪfɔɹ, hid lɛft ɪt bɛɾɝ ðən wən hiɾ ɝaɪvd. ɹænd hæd ɹimuv fɔɹseɪkən taɪɹəns, bɹɔɾ ən ɛn tə wɔɹfɛɹ ən sidʒəz. hid kæst aʊt ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪnveɪɾɝz, hid dɪlɪvɝd fud, hid kɹieɪɾəd stəbɪlɪɾi. itʃ læn hid dɪstʃɹɔɪd hæd, ɪsɛnʃəli, bɪn seɪvd ət ðə seɪm taɪm.

Each time he'd conquered a kingdom before, he'd left it better than when he'd arrived. Rand had removed Forsaken tyrants, brought an end to warfare and sieges. He'd cast out Shaido invaders, he'd delivered food, he'd created stability. Each land he'd destroyed had, essentially, been saved at the same time.

ɑɹæd dumən wɑz dɪfɹənt. hid bɹɔɾ ɪn fud - bʌt ðət fud hæd dʒɹɔn ivən mɔɹ ɹɛfjudʒiz, stʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪz səplaɪz. nɑɾ oʊnli hæɾ i feɪl tə ɡɪv əm pis wɪð ðə sintʃæn, hi hæɾ əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪd ðɛɹ oʊnli tʃɹups ən sɛn əm ʌp tə wɑtʃ ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðə siz wɝ stɪl ənseɪf.

Arad Doman was different. He'd brought in food - but that food had drawn even more refugees, straining his supplies. Not only had he failed to give them peace with the Seanchan, he had appropriated their only troops and sent them up to watch the Borderlands. The seas were still unsafe.

ðə taɪni sintʃæn ɛmpɹɛs hædn tʃɹʌstɪd hɪm. ʃi wəd kəntɪnju hɝ ətæks, pɝhæps dʌbəl ðɛm.

The tiny Seanchan empress hadn't trusted him. She would continue her attacks, perhaps double them.

ðə dəmɑni wəd bi tʃɹæmpəl bɪniθ ðə hʊvz ʌv wɔɹ, kɹʌʃt bɪtwin ði ɪnveɪɾɪŋ tʃɹɑləks tə ðə nɔɹθ ən ðə sintʃæn tə ðə saʊθ. ən ɹænd wɑz livɪŋ ðɛm.

The Domani would be trampled beneath the hooves of war, crushed between the invading Trollocs to the north and the Seanchan to the south. And Rand was leaving them.

sʌmhaʊ, ðə pipəl ɹilaɪz ðæt, ən ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd fəɹ ɹænd tə lʊk ət ðɛm. ðɛɹ hʌŋɡɹi aɪz əkjuz hɪm: waɪ bɹɪŋ hoʊp, ðən lɛɾ ɪt dʒɹaɪ ʌp, laɪk ə nuli dʌɡ wɛl dʊɹɪŋ ə dʒɹaʊt? waɪ fɔɹs əs tə æksɛp jə əz əɹ ɹulɝ, oʊnli tə əbændən ʌs?

Somehow, the people realized that, and it was very hard for Rand to look at them. Their hungry eyes accused him: Why bring hope, then let it dry up, like a newly dug well during a drought? Why force us to accept you as our ruler, only to abandon us?

flɪn ən nf hæd ɹɪɾən bɪfɔɹ hɪm; hi kəd si ðɛɹ blæk koʊts əhɛɾ əz ðeɪ sæt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɑtʃɪŋ ɹændz pɹəsɛʃən əpɹoʊtʃ ðə sɪɾi skwɛɹ. ðə pɪnz spɑɹkəld ɑn ðɛɹ haɪ kɑlɝz.

Flinn and Naeff had ridden before him; he could see their black coats ahead as they sat their horses watching Rand's procession approach the city square. The pins sparkled on their high collars.

ðə faʊntən ɪn ðə skwɛɹ stɪl floʊɾ əmʌŋ ɡlimɪŋ kɑpɝ hɔɹsəz lipɪŋ fɹəm kɑpɝ weɪvz.

The fountain in the square still flowed among gleaming copper horses leaping from copper waves.

wɪtʃ ə ðoʊz saɪlən dəmɑni kəntɪnjud tə ʃaɪn ðə faʊntən, wən noʊ kɪŋ ɹuld ən hæf ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl wɑz lɔst?

Which of those silent Domani continued to shine the fountain, when no king ruled and half the merchant council was lost?

ɹændz il hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə tʃɹæk daʊn ɪnʌf ə ðə kaʊnsəl tə fɔɹm ə mədʒɔɹəɾi; hi səspɛktəd ðət ɡɹeɪndəl hæd kɪld əɹ kæptʃɝɾ ɪnʌf ə ðɛm tə kip ə nu kɪŋ fɹəm ɛvɝ biɪŋ tʃoʊzən. ɪf ɛni ʌv ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl mɛmbɝz hæd bɪn pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf, ðeɪɾ əv dʒɔɪn ðə ɹæŋks ə hɝ pɛts -  wɪtʃ mɛn ðət ɹænd hæd kɪl ðɛm.

Rand's Aiel hadn't been able to track down enough of the council to form a majority; he suspected that Graendal had killed or captured enough of them to keep a new king from ever being chosen. If any of the merchant council members had been pretty enough, they'd have joined the ranks of her pets -  which meant that Rand had killed them.

ɑ, luz θɝɪn sɛd. neɪmz aɪ kən æd tə ðə lɪst. jɛs. . . .

Ah, Lews Therin said. Names I can add to the list. Yes. . . .

bæʃɪɹ ɹoʊɾ ʌp bɪsaɪd ɹænd, nʌklɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz, lʊkɪŋ θɔtfəl. "jɔɹ wɪl ɪz dʌn,"

Bashere rode up beside Rand, knuckling his mustaches, looking thoughtful. "Your will is done,"

hi sɛd.

he said.

"leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝ?" ɹænd æskt.

"Lady Chadmar?" Rand asked.

"ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ mænʃən," bæʃɪɹ sɛd. "wiv dʌn ðə seɪm wɪð ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ mɛmbɝz ə ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl ði il wɝ hoʊldɪŋ nɪɹ ðə sɪɾi."

"Returned to her mansion," Bashere said. "We've done the same with the other four members of the merchant council the Aiel were holding near the city."

"ðeɪ ʌndɝstænd wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ tə du?"

"They understand what they are to do?"

"jɛs," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, saɪɪŋ. "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəl də ɪt. ɪf jə æsk mi, ðə moʊmənt wɝ ɡɔn ðəl boʊl fɹəm ðə sɪɾi laɪk θivz fliɪŋ ə pɹɪzən wʌns ðə ɡɑɹdz liv."

"Yes," Bashere said, sighing. "But I don't think they'll do it. If you ask me, the moment we're gone they'll bolt from the city like thieves fleeing a prison once the guards leave."

ɹænd ɡeɪv noʊ ɹiækʃən. hiɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðə mɝtʃən kaʊnsəl tə tʃuz nu mɛmbɝz, ðən pɪk ə kɪŋ. bʌt bæʃɪɹ wɑz pɹɑbli ɹaɪt. ɔlɹɛɾi, ɹænd hæd ɹɪpɔɹts fɹəm ði ʌðɝ sɪɾiz əlɔŋ ðə koʊst, wɛɹ hid toʊld ɪz il tə wɪðdʒɹɔ. ðə sɪɾi liɾɝz wɝ vænɪʃɪŋ, ɹʌnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə pɹəzum sintʃæn əsɔlt.

Rand gave no reaction. He'd ordered the merchant council to choose new members, then pick a king. But Bashere was probably right. Already, Rand had reports from the other cities along the coast, where he'd told his Aiel to withdraw. The city leaders were vanishing, running before the presumed Seanchan assault.

ɑɹæd dumən, əz ə kɪŋdəm, wɑz fɪnɪʃt. laɪk ə teɪbəl leɪɾən wɪð tu mʌtʃ weɪt, ɪt wəd sun kəlæps. ɪts nɑt maɪ pɹɑbləm, ɹænd θɔt, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət ðə pipəl. aɪ dɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ kʊd.

Arad Doman, as a kingdom, was finished. Like a table laden with too much weight, it would soon collapse. It is not my problem, Rand thought, not looking at the people. I did everything I could.

ðət wɑzn tʃɹu. ðoʊ hid wɑntəd tə hɛlp ðə dəmɑni, hɪz ɹil ɹizənz fəɹ kʌmɪŋ hæd bɪn tə dil wɪð ðə sintʃæn, tə faɪn aʊt wʌt hæd hæpən tə ðə kɪŋ, ən tə tʃɹæk daʊn ɡɹeɪndəl. nɑt tə mɛnʃən tə sɪkjʊɹ wʌɾ i kəɾ ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz.

That wasn't true. Though he'd wanted to help the Domani, his real reasons for coming had been to deal with the Seanchan, to find out what had happened to the king, and to track down Graendal. Not to mention to secure what he could of the Borderlands.

"wʌt nuz fɹəm ɪɾɝɑldi?" ɹænd æskt.

"What news from Ituralde?" Rand asked.

"nʌθɪŋ ɡʊd, aɪm əfɹeɪd," bæʃɪɹ sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "hiz hæd skɝmɪʃɪz wɪð tʃɹɑləks, bʌt jə nu ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ðə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ɔlweɪz wɪðdʒɹɔ kwɪkli, bʌɾ i wɔɹnz ðət sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɡæðɝɪŋ. hɪz skaʊts kætʃ ɡlɪmpsɪz ə fɔɹsɪz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝɹʌn hɪm. ɪf ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ ðɛɹ, ðən ðəɹ laɪkli ɡæðɝɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ əz wɛl. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðə ɡæp."

"Nothing good, I'm afraid," Bashere said grimly. "He's had skirmishes with Trollocs, but you knew that already. The Shadowspawn always withdraw quickly, but he warns that something is gathering. His scouts catch glimpses of forces large enough to overrun him. If the Trollocs are gathering there, then they're likely gathering elsewhere as well. Particularly the Gap."

kɝs ðoʊz bɔɹɾɝləndɝz! ɹænd θɔt. əl əv tə də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm. sun.

Curse those Borderlanders! Rand thought. I will have to do something about them. Soon.

ɹitʃɪŋ ðə skwɛɹ, hi ɹeɪn ɪn teɪdeɪʃɝ ən nɑɾəd tə flɪn ən nf.

Reaching the square, he reined in Tai'daishar and nodded to Flinn and Naeff.

əɾ ɪz sɪɡnəl, ðeɪ itʃ oʊpən ə lɑɹdʒ ɡeɪtweɪ ɪn ðə sɪɾi skwɛɹ. ɹænd hæd wɑntəd tə liv dɝɛkli fɹəm leɪɾi tʃædmɑɝz mænʃən ɡɹaʊnz, bʌt ðət wʊɾə bɪn tə vænɪʃ laɪk ə θif, ðəɹ wʌn deɪ ən ɡɔn ðə nɛkst. hi wəɾ ət lis lɛt ðə pipəl si ðəɾ i wɑz livɪŋ ən noʊ ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn lɛf tə ðɛmsɛlvz.

At his signal, they each opened a large gateway in the city square. Rand had wanted to leave directly from Lady Chadmar's mansion grounds, but that would have been to vanish like a thief, there one day and gone the next. He would at least let the people see that he was leaving and know that they had been left to themselves.

ðeɪ laɪn ðə bɔɹdwɔks, mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ hæd wən ɹænd hæd fɝst ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi. ɪf pɑsəbəl, ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ kwaɪət naʊ ðən ðeɪ hæd bɪn. wɪmən ɪn ðɛɹ slik ɡaʊnz, mɛn ɪn kʌlɝfəl koʊts ən ɹʌfəl slivz bɪniθ. ðəɹ wɝ mɛni wɪθaʊt ðə kɑpɝi skɪn ə ðə dəmɑni. ɹænd hæd lʊɹd soʊ mɛni tə ðə sɪɾi wɪð pɹɑməsəz ə fud.

They lined the boardwalks, much as they had when Rand had first entered the city. If possible, they were more quiet now than they had been. Women in their sleek gowns, men in colorful coats and ruffled sleeves beneath. There were many without the coppery skin of the Domani. Rand had lured so many to the city with promises of food.

taɪm tə ɡoʊ. hi əpɹoʊtʃt wʌn ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪz, bʌɾ ə vɔɪs kɔld aʊt. "lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən!"

Time to go. He approached one of the gateways, but a voice called out. "Lord Dragon!"

ðə vɔɪs wɑz izi tə hɪɹ, sɪns ðə kɹaʊdz wɝ soʊ saɪlənt. ɹænd tɝn ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, sikɪŋ aʊt ðə sɔɹs ə ðə vɔɪs. ə wɪləwi mæn ɪn ə ɹɛd dəmɑni koʊt - bʌɾənd ət ðə weɪst, oʊpən ɪn ə "vi" ʌp ðə fɹʌnt, wɪð ə ɹʌfəld ʃɝt bɪniθ. hɪz ɡoʊldən ɪɹɪŋz spɑɹkəld əz i ɛlboʊɾ ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd. ði il ɪntɝsɛptəd hɪm, bʌt ɹænd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪm əz wʌn ə ðə dɑkmæstɝz.

The voice was easy to hear, since the crowds were so silent. Rand turned in his saddle, seeking out the source of the voice. A willowy man in a red Domani coat - buttoned at the waist, open in a "V" up the front, with a ruffled shirt beneath. His golden earrings sparkled as he elbowed his way through the crowd. The Aiel intercepted him, but Rand recognized him as one of the dockmasters.

ɹænd nɑɾəd fəɹ ði il tə lɛt ðə mæn - aɪɹlɪn wɑz ɪz neɪm - əpɹoʊtʃ.

Rand nodded for the Aiel to let the man - Iralin was his name - approach.

aɪɹlɪn hɝiɾ ʌp tə teɪdeɪʃɝ. hi wɑz ʌnkɛɹɪktɝɪstɪkli klin ʃeɪvən fəɹ ə dəmɑni mæn, ən ɪz aɪz wɝ ʃæɾoʊd fɹəm læk ə slip.

Iralin hurried up to Tai'daishar. He was uncharacteristically clean shaven for a Domani man, and his eyes were shadowed from lack of sleep.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ðə mæn sɛɾ ɪn ə hʌʃt vɔɪs, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ɹændz hɔɹs, "ðə fud! ɪts spɔɪld."

"My Lord Dragon," the man said in a hushed voice, standing beside Rand's horse, "The food! It has spoiled."

"wʌt fud?" ɹænd æskt.

"What food?" Rand asked.

"ɔl ʌv ɪt," ðə mæn sɛd, vɔɪs tɔt. "ɛvɹi bæɹəl, ɛvɹi sæk, ɛvɹi bɪɾ ɪn əɹ stɔɹz ən ɪn ðə si foʊk ʃɪps. maɪ lɔɹd! ɪts nɑt dʒʌs fʊl ʌv wivəlz. ɪts ɡɹoʊn blæk ən bɪɾɝ, ən ɪt meɪks mɛn sɪk tə iɾ ɪt!"

"All of it," the man said, voice taut. "Every barrel, every sack, every bit in our stores and in the Sea Folk ships. My Lord! It's not just full of weevils. It's grown black and bitter, and it makes men sick to eat it!"

"ɔl ʌv ɪt?" hi ɹɪpiɾɪd, ʃɑkt.

"All of it?" he repeated, shocked.

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ," aɪɹlɪn sɛd sɔfli. "hʌnʒɹədz əpɑn hʌnʒɹədz ə bæɹəlz. ɪt hæpən sʌɾənli, ɪn ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ. wʌn moʊmənt, ɪt wɑz ɡʊd, ðə nɛks moʊmənt. . . . maɪ lɔɹd, soʊ mɛni pipəl əv kʌm tə ðə sɪɾi kəz ðeɪ hɝd wi hæd fud! naʊ wɪv nʌθɪŋ. wʌt wɪl wi du?"

"Everything," Iralin said softly. "Hundreds upon hundreds of barrels. It happened suddenly, in the blink of an eye. One moment, it was good, the next moment. . . . My Lord, so many people have come to the city because they heard we had food! Now we have nothing. What will we do?"

ɹænd kloʊzd ɪz aɪz.

Rand closed his eyes.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" aɪɹlɪn æskt.

"My Lord?" Iralin asked.

ɹænd oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən kɪk teɪdeɪʃɝ ɪndə moʊʃən. hi lɛf ðə dɑkmæstɝ bɪhaɪnd, maʊθ oʊpən, ən pæs θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ɹænd kəd du. nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ i wəd du.

Rand opened his eyes and kicked Tai'daishar into motion. He left the dockmaster behind, mouth open, and passed through the gateway. There was nothing more Rand could do. Nothing more he would do.

hi pʊt ðə kʌmɪŋ stɑɹveɪʃən aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. ɪt wɑz ʃɑkɪŋ haʊ izi ðət wɑz.

He put the coming starvation out of his mind. It was shocking how easy that was.

bændɑɹ ɛbən vænɪʃt, ðoʊz tu-saɪlən pipəl vænɪʃt. ðə moʊmən i pæs θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, tʃɪɹz ɪksploʊɾəd fɹəm ðə weɪɾɪŋ kɹaʊdz. ɪt wɑz soʊ ʃɑkɪŋ, sətʃ ə kɑntʃɹæst, ðət ɹænd pʊl teɪdeɪʃɝ ʌp ʃɔɹt, stʌnd.

Bandar Eban vanished, those too-silent people vanished. The moment he passed through the gateway, cheers exploded from the waiting crowds. It was so shocking, such a contrast, that Rand pulled Tai'daishar up short, stunned.

tɛɹ spɹɛd bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ðɪs wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz, mæsɪv ən spɹɔlɪŋ, ən ðə ɡeɪtweɪz oʊpən dɝɛkli ɪndə fistɝz ɹʌn, wʌn ə ðə meɪn sɪɾi skwɛɹz. ə ʃɔɹt ɹæŋk ʌv æʃəmən səluɾəd wɪð fɪsts tə tʃɛsts. ɹænd hæd sɛn əm ɑn ɝliɝ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ tə pɹipɛɹ ðə sɪɾi fəɹ ɪz ɝaɪvəl ən klɪɹ ðə skwɛɹ fəɹ ɡeɪtweɪz.

Tear spread before him. This was one of the great cities, massive and sprawling, and the gateways opened directly into Feaster's Run, one of the main city squares. A short rank of Asha'man saluted with fists to chests. Rand had sent them on earlier in the morning to prepare the city for his arrival and clear the square for gateways.

ðə pipəl kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ tʃɪɹz. θaʊzənz hæd ɡæðɝd, ən bænɝz ə laɪt flæpt ətɑp dʌzənz ə poʊlz hɛld əlɔf baɪ ðə kɹaʊd. ði ædʒəleɪʃən hɪt ɹænd laɪk ə weɪv ə ɹipɹoʊtʃ. hi dɪdn dɪzɝv sətʃ pɹeɪz. nɑɾ æftɝ wʌɾ i hæd dʌn ɪn ɑɹæd dumən.

The people continued their cheers. Thousands had gathered, and Banners of Light flapped atop dozens of poles held aloft by the crowd. The adulation hit Rand like a wave of reproach. He didn't deserve such praise. Not after what he had done in Arad Doman.

mʌs kip muvɪŋ, hi θɔt, kɪkɪŋ teɪdeɪʃɝ ɪndə moʊʃən əɡɛn. ðə hɔɹsəz hʊvz fɛl ɑn flæɡstoʊnz hɪɹ, ɹæðɝ ðən ɹeɪn-dæmpən dɝt. bændɑɹ ɛbən wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾi, bʌt tiɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɪntaɪɝli. stʃɹits sneɪkt əkɹɔs ðə lændskeɪp, laɪnd wɪð bɪldɪŋz ðət moʊs kʌntʃɹi foʊk wʊɾə kɔl kɹæmpt, bʌt ðət wɝ ɔɹɾənɛɹi tə ðə tɛɹənz. mɛni ʌv ðə pik sleɪɾ əɹ taɪl ɹufs hæd mɛn əɹ bɔɪz pɝtʃt ɑn ðɛɹ ɛdʒəz, hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ ə bɛɾɝ vju ʌv ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. ðə bɪldɪŋ stoʊnz wɝ ə laɪɾɝ hju hɪɹ ðən ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən, ən ðeɪ wɝ ðə pɹəfɝd bɪldɪŋ mətɪɹiəl. pɝhæps ðət wɑz kəz ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ðət lumd əbʌv ðə sɪɾi. ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ, ɪt wɑz kɔld. ə ɹɛlɪk ʌv ə pɹiviəs eɪdʒ, stɪl ɪmpɹɛsɪv.

Must keep moving, he thought, kicking Tai'daishar into motion again. The horse's hooves fell on flagstones here, rather than rain-dampened dirt. Bandar Eban was a large city, but Tear was something else entirely. Streets snaked across the landscape, lined with buildings that most country folk would have called cramped, but that were ordinary to the Tairens. Many of the peaked slate or tile roofs had men or boys perched on their edges, hoping for a better view of the Lord Dragon. The building stones were a lighter hue here than they had been in Bandar Eban, and they were the preferred building material. Perhaps that was because of the fortress that loomed above the city. The Stone of Tear, it was called. A relic of a previous age, still impressive.

ɹænd tʃɹɑɾəd fɔɹwɝd, mɪn ən bæʃɪɹ stɪl ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ. ðoʊz kɹaʊdz ɹɔɹd. soʊ laʊd.

Rand trotted forward, Min and Bashere still riding nearby. Those crowds roared. So loud.

nɪɹbaɪ, tu flæpɪŋ pɛndəns ɡɑt kɑɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd, ən ɪnɪksplɪkəbli ɛntæŋɡəld. ðə mɛn hoʊldɪŋ əm əlɔft, nɪɹ ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kɹaʊd, loʊɝɾ əm ən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl əm əpɑɹt, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾɪd taɪt, sʌmhaʊ twɪstəd ðət weɪ baɪ ðə wɪnd. ɹænd pæst əm wɪð bɛɹli ɛni noʊɾəs. hid stɑp filɪŋ sɝpɹaɪz ət wʌɾ ɪz tɑvɝən neɪtʃɝ kəd du.

Nearby, two flapping pendants got caught in the wind, and inexplicably entangled. The men holding them aloft, near the front of the crowd, lowered them and tried to pull them apart, but they were knotted tight, somehow twisted that way by the wind. Rand passed them with barely any notice. He'd stopped feeling surprise at what his ta'veren nature could do.

ɹænd wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd, haʊɛvɝ, tə si soʊ mɛni fɔɹənɝz ɪn ðə kɹaʊd. ðət wɑzn soʊ ənjuʒəwəl;

Rand was surprised, however, to see so many foreigners in the crowd. That wasn't so unusual;

tɛɹ ɔlweɪz sɔ ə lɑɾ ʌv aʊtləndɝz - ɪt wɛlkəm ðoʊz u wəd tʃɹeɪd spaɪsəz ən sɪlks fɹəm ði ist, pɔɹsələn fɹəm ðə siz, ɡɹeɪnz əɹ təbæk fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ, ən stɔɹiz fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ ðeɪ kəd bi ɡlind. haʊɛvɝ, ɹænd hæd faʊn ðəɾ aʊtləndɝz - noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə sɪɾi - peɪɾ ɪm lɛs hid wən i vɪzəɾəd. ðɪs wɑz tʃɹu ivən wən ðoʊz aʊtləndɝz wɝ fɹəm ənʌðɝ kʌntʃɹi hi hæd kɑŋkɝd. wən i wɑz ɪn kɛɹhin, ðə kɛɹhinɪn wəd fɔn oʊvɝ ɪm - bʌɾ ɪf i wɝ ɪn ɪljən, ðə kɛɹhinɪn wəɾ əvɔɪd hɪm. pɝhæps ðeɪ dɪdn laɪk biɪŋ ɹimaɪndəd ðət ðɛɹ lɔɹɾ ən ðɛɹ ɛnəmiz lɔɹd wɝ ðə seɪm mæn.

Tear always saw a lot of outlanders - it welcomed those who would trade spices and silks from the east, porcelain from the seas, grains or tabac from the north, and stories from anywhere they could be gleaned. However, Rand had found that outlanders - no matter what the city - paid him less heed when he visited. This was true even when those outlanders were from another country he had conquered. When he was in Cairhien, the Cairhienin would fawn over him - but if he were in Illian, the Cairhienin would avoid him. Perhaps they didn't like being reminded that their lord and their enemy's lord were the same man.

hɪɹ, haʊɛvɝ, hi hæd noʊ tʃɹʌbəl kaʊntɪŋ fɔɹənɝz: si foʊk wɪð ðɛɹ dɑɹk skɪn ən ðɛɹ lus, bɹaɪt kloʊðɪŋ; mʊɹændiənz, ɪn ðɛɹ lɔŋ koʊts ən wæks mʌstæʃɪz; bɪɹɾəd ɪliɑnɝz wɪð ʌptɝn kɑlɝz; peɪl-feɪs kɛɹhinɪn wɪð stʃɹaɪps ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlsoʊ mɛn ən wɪmən u wɔɹ sɪmpəl ændɔɝən wʊl. fjuɝ ə ðə fɔɹənɝz tʃɪɹd ðən loʊkəlz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ðɛɹ, wɑtʃfəl.

Here, however, he had no trouble counting foreigners: Sea Folk with their dark skin and their loose, bright clothing; Murandians, in their long coats and waxed mustaches; bearded Illianers with upturned collars; pale-faced Cairhienin with stripes on their clothing. There were also men and women who wore simple Andoran wool. Fewer of the foreigners cheered than locals, but they were there, watchful.

bæʃɪɹ skæn ðə kɹaʊd.

Bashere scanned the crowd.

"ðə pipəl sim sɝpɹaɪzd," ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf seɪɪŋ.

"The people seem surprised," Rand found himself saying.

"juv bɪn əweɪ fəɹ ə taɪm." bæʃɪɹ nʌkəld ɪz mʌstæʃɪz ɪn θɔt. "noʊ daʊt ðə ɹumɝz əv floʊn swɪftɝ ðən æɹoʊz, ən mɛni ən ɪnkipɝ əz spʌn teɪlz ə jəɹ dɛθ əɹ dɪsəpɪɹəns tə ɛnkɝɪdʒ ənʌðɝ ɹaʊn ə dʒɹɪŋks."

"You've been away for a time." Bashere knuckled his mustaches in thought. "No doubt the rumors have flown swifter than arrows, and many an innkeeper has spun tales of your death or disappearance to encourage another round of drinks."

"laɪt! aɪ sim tə spɛn hæf ə maɪ laɪf tʃɹæmplɪŋ daʊn wʌn ɹumɝ əɹ ənʌðɝ. wən wɪl ɪɾ ɛnd?"

"Light! I seem to spend half of my life trampling down one rumor or another. When will it end?"

bæʃɪɹ læft. "wɛn jə kən stɑp ɹumɝ ɪtsɛlf, əl ɡɛɾ ɔf maɪ hɔɹs ən ɹaɪɾ ə ɡoʊt! hɑ! ən bɪkʌm wʌn ə ðə si foʊk əz wɛl."

Bashere laughed. "When you can stop rumor itself, I'll get off my horse and ride a goat! Ha! And become one of the Sea Folk as well."

ɹænd fɛl saɪlənt. hɪz fɑloʊɝz kəntɪnjud tə paɪl θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪz. əz ðə sɑldəiənz ɛntɝd tɛɹ, nɪɹli tə ə mæn ðeɪ hɛl ðɛɹ lænsɪz ʌp stʃɹeɪɾɝ, ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz pɹænsɪŋ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wʊdn bi kɑt pɹinɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd lʊk lɛs wɪltɪd, ðɛɹ eɪdʒləs feɪsəz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə kɹaʊd wɪð ə sɑɡæʃəs mænɝ. ən ði il - ðɛɹ pɹaʊlɪŋ stɛps ə lɪɾəl lɛs wɛɹi, ðɛɹ ɪkspɹɛʃənz lɛs ɡɑɹɾəd - simd mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð ðə tʃɪɹɪŋ ðən ðeɪ hæd wɪð ðoʊz kwaɪət, əkjuzɪŋ dəmɑni aɪz.

Rand fell silent. His followers continued to pile through the gateways. As the Saldaeans entered Tear, nearly to a man they held their lances up straighter, their horses prancing. The Aes Sedai wouldn't be caught preening, but they did look less wilted, their ageless faces regarding the crowd with a sagacious manner. And the Aiel - their prowling steps a little less wary, their expressions less guarded - seemed more comfortable with the cheering than they had with those quiet, accusing Domani eyes.

bæʃɪɹ ən ɹænd muvd oʊvɝ tə ðə saɪd, mɪn fɑloʊɪŋ saɪlənli. ʃi lʊk dɪstʃɹæktəd.

Bashere and Rand moved over to the side, Min following silently. She looked distracted.

nɪneɪiv ən kædzueɪn hæd nɑt bɪn ɪn ðə mænʃən wən ɹænd hæɾ ənaʊnst ɪz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. wʌt kəd ðeɪ bi ʌp tə? hi daʊɾɪd ðeɪ wɝ təɡɛðɝ; ðoʊz wɪmən bɛɹli tɑlɝeɪɾəd biɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm ɹum. ɛniweɪ, ðeɪ wəd hɪɹ wɛɹ i hæd ɡɔn, ən ðeɪ wəd faɪn hɪm. fɹəm ðɪs pɔɪn ɑn, ɹænd wəd bi izi tə loʊkeɪt. noʊ mɔɹ haɪɾɪŋ ɪn wʊɾɪd mænɝz. noʊ mɔɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ əloʊn. nɑt wɪð læn ən ɪz mɔlkɪɹi ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə ɡæp. ðəɹ wɑzn ɪnʌf taɪm lɛft.

Nynaeve and Cadsuane had not been in the mansion when Rand had announced his departure. What could they be up to? He doubted they were together; those women barely tolerated being in the same room. Anyway, they would hear where he had gone, and they would find him. From this point on, Rand would be easy to locate. No more hiding in wooded manors. No more traveling alone. Not with Lan and his Malkieri riding to the Gap. There wasn't enough time left.

bæʃɪɹ wɑtʃt ði oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪz, ði il pæsɪŋ θɹu ɑn saɪlən fit. ðɪs mɛθəɾ ə vɔɪɑdʒɪŋ wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ fəmɪljɝ tə ðɛm.

Bashere watched the open gateways, the Aiel passing through on silent feet. This method of voyaging was becoming familiar to them.

"ɑɹ jə gɑnə tɛl ɪɾɝɑldi?" bæʃɪɹ faɪnəli æskt. "əbaʊt jəɹ wɪðdʒɹɔəl?"

"Are you going to tell Ituralde?" Bashere finally asked. "About your withdrawal?"

"hi wɪl hɪɹ," ɹænd sɛd. "hɪz mɛsənʒɝz wɝ ɔɹɾɝd tə bɹɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts tə bændɑɹ ɛbən. ðəl sun dɪskʌvɝ ɪm noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðɛɹ."

"He will hear," Rand said. "His messengers were ordered to bring reports to Bandar Eban. They will soon discover I'm no longer there."

"æn ɪf i livz ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz tə ɹɪzum ɪz wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn?"

"And if he leaves the Borderlands to resume his war against the Seanchan?"

"ðɛn hɪl sloʊ ðə sintʃæn daʊn," ɹænd sɛd. "æn kip əm fɹəm nɪpɪŋ ət maɪ hilz. ðət wɪl bi əz ɡʊɾ ə jus fəɹ ɪm əz ɛni."

"Then he'll slow the Seanchan down," Rand said. "And keep them from nipping at my heels. That will be as good a use for him as any."

bæʃɪɹ aɪd hɪm.

Bashere eyed him.

"wʌt dʒju ɪkspɛk mi tə du, bæʃɪɹ?" ɹænd æskt kwaɪətli. ðət lʊk wɑz ə tʃælənʒ, ɪf ə sʌɾəl wʌn, bʌt ɹænd wəd nɑt ɹaɪz tə ɪt. hɪz æŋɡɝ ɹɪmeɪn fɹoʊzən.

"What do you expect me to do, Bashere?" Rand asked quietly. That look was a challenge, if a subtle one, but Rand would not rise to it. His anger remained frozen.

bæʃɪɹ saɪd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ," hi sɛd. "ðɪs hoʊl θɪŋ ɪz ə mɛs, ən aɪ doʊn si ɛni weɪ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, mæn. ɡoʊɪŋ tə wɔɹ wɪð ðə sintʃæn əɾ əɹ bæks, ðæts əz bæɾ ə pəzɪʃən əz aɪ kən θɪŋk ʌv."

Bashere sighed. "I don't know," he said. "This whole thing is a mess, and I don't see any way out of it, man. Going to war with the Seanchan at our backs, that's as bad a position as I can think of."

"aɪ noʊ," ɹænd sɛd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi. "tiɹ wɪl bi ðɛɹz baɪ ðə taɪm ðɪs ɪz θɹu, pɹɑbli ɪljən əz wɛl. bɝn mi, bʌt wɪl bi lʌki ɪf ðeɪ doʊn kɑŋkɝ ɔl ðə weɪ ʌp tə ændɝ waɪl əɹ bæks ɑɹ tɝnd."

"I know," Rand said, looking over the city. "Tear will be theirs by the time this is through, probably Illian as well. Burn me, but we'll be lucky if they don't conquer all the way up to Andor while our backs are turned."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"wi hæv tə əsum ðəɾ ɪɾɝɑldi wɪl əbændən ɪz poʊst wʌns nuz ə maɪ feɪljɝ ɹitʃəz hɪm. ðət minz əɹ nɛks muv əz tə bi təwɔɹd ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ ɑɹmi. wʌtɛvɝ kəmpleɪn jəɹ kɪnsmɪn əv wɪð mi, ɪt mʌs bi sɛɾəld kwɪkli. aɪ hæv lɪɾəl peɪʃəns fəɹ mɛn u əbændən ðɛɹ duɾiz."

"We have to assume that Ituralde will abandon his post once news of my failure reaches him. That means our next move has to be toward the Borderlander army. Whatever complaint your kinsmen have with me, it must be settled quickly. I have little patience for men who abandon their duties."

hæv wi dʌn ðæt? luz θɝɪn æskt. hu hæv wi əbændənd?

Have we done that? Lews Therin asked. Who have we abandoned?

kwaɪət! ɹænd ɡɹaʊld. ɡoʊ bæk tə jəɹ tɪɹz, mædmæn, ən liv mi bi!

Quiet! Rand growled. Go back to your tears, madman, and leave me be!

bæʃɪɹ lin bæk θɔtfəli ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. ɪf i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ə ɹænd əbændənɪŋ ðə dəmɑni, hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ. faɪnəli, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt tɛnoʊbiə ɪz əbaʊt. kəd bi əz sɪmpəl əz əɹ æŋɡɝ ət mi fəɹ livɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ju; kəd bi əz dɪfəkəlt əz ə dɪmæn ðət jə səbmɪt tə ðə wɪl ə ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ mɑnɑɹks. aɪ kæn ɪmædʒən wʌt wəd dʒɹɔ hɝ ən ði ʌðɝz əweɪ fɹəm ðə blaɪɾ əɾ ə taɪm laɪk ðɪs."

Bashere leaned back thoughtfully in his saddle. If he was thinking of Rand abandoning the Domani, he said nothing. Finally, he shook his head. "I don't know what Tenobia is about. Could be as simple as her anger at me for leaving to follow you; could be as difficult as a demand that you submit to the will of the Borderlander monarchs. I can't imagine what would draw her and the others away from the Blight at a time like this."

"wi wɪl sun faɪn aʊt," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ wɑn jə tə teɪk ə kʌpəl ə ði æʃəmən ən faɪn aʊt wɛɹ tɛnoʊbiə ən ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ kæmpt. meɪbi wɪl dɪskʌvɝ ðeɪv ɡɪvən ʌp ðɪs fulz pɝeɪɾ ən tɝn bæk təwɔɹd wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ."

"We will soon find out," Rand said. "I want you to take a couple of the Asha'man and find out where Tenobia and the others are camped. Maybe we'll discover they've given up this fool's parade and turned back toward where they belong."

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn," bæʃɪɹ sɛd. "lɛt mi si maɪ mɛn sɛɾəld ən əl bi ɔf."

"All right, then," Bashere said. "Let me see my men settled and I'll be off."

ɹænd nɑɾəd ʃɑɹpli, ðən tɝn ɪz maʊn ən bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɑt daʊn ðə stʃɹit. ðə pipəl wɝ laɪn ʌp ɑn iðɝ saɪd, ʌʃɝɪŋ ɪm ɔnwɝd. ðə læs taɪm i hæd vɪzəɾəd tɛɹ, hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kʌm ɪn dɪsɡaɪz, fəɹ ɔl ðə ɡʊɾ ɪt hæd dʌn hɪm. ɛniwʌn u nu ðə saɪnz wʊɾə noʊn i wɑz ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ənjuʒəwəl ɪvɛns - bænɝz taɪɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz təɡɛðɝ, mɛn fɔlɪŋ fɹəm bɪldɪŋz ən lændɪŋ ənhɑɹmd - wɝ oʊnli ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. hɪz tɑvɝən ɪfɛk sim tə bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ paʊɝfəl, kɑzɪŋ ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɡɹeɪɾɝ dɪstɔɹʃənz. ən mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs wʌnz.

Rand nodded sharply, then turned his mount and began to trot down the street. The people were lined up on either side, ushering him onward. The last time he had visited Tear, he had tried to come in disguise, for all the good it had done him. Anyone who knew the signs would have known he was in the city. Unusual events - banners tying themselves together, men falling from buildings and landing unharmed - were only the beginning. His ta'veren effect seemed to be growing more powerful, causing increasingly greater distortions. And more dangerous ones.

dʊɹɪŋ ɪz læs vɪzət, tiɹ hæd bɪn bɪsidʒ baɪ ɹɛbəlz, bʌt ðə sɪɾi hædn sʌfɝd. tiɹ hæd tu mʌtʃ tʃɹeɪd tə bi bɑðɝd baɪ sʌmθɪŋ əz sɪmpəl əz ə sidʒ. moʊs pipəl hæd lɪvd əz juʒəwəl, bɛɹli æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ðə ɹɛbəlz. noʊbəlz kəd pleɪ ðɛɹ ɡeɪmz, əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ dɪdn dɪsɹʌp mɔɹ ɑnəs foʊks.

During his last visit, Tear had been besieged by rebels, but the city hadn't suffered. Tear had too much trade to be bothered by something as simple as a siege. Most people had lived as usual, barely acknowledging the rebels. Nobles could play their games, as long as they didn't disrupt more honest folks.

bɪsaɪdz, ɛvɹiwʌn hæd noʊn ðət ðə stoʊn wəd hoʊld, əz ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz hæd. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ɹɛndɝɾ ɑbsəlit baɪ tʃɹævlɪŋ, bʌt fəɹ ɪnveɪɾɝz u dɪdn əv æksɛs tə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ðə stoʊn wɑz vɝtʃuəli ɪmpɑsəbəl tə teɪk. ɪn ən ʌv ɪtsɛlf, ɪt wɑz mɔɹ mæsɪv ðən mɛni sɪɾiz - ə ɡɑɹɡæntʃuən spɹɔl ʌv wɔlz, taʊɝz ən ʃɪɹ fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz wɪθaʊɾ ə sɪŋɡəl sim ɪn ɪts ɹɑk. ɪɾ ɪnkluɾəd fɔɹdʒɪz, wɛɹhaʊzɪz, θaʊzənz ə dɪfɛndɝz, ən ɪts oʊn fɔɹɾəfaɪd dɑk.

Besides, everyone had known that the Stone would hold, as it almost always had. It might have been rendered obsolete by Traveling, but for invaders who didn't have access to the One Power, the Stone was virtually impossible to take. In and of itself, it was more massive than many cities - a gargantuan sprawl of walls, towers and sheer fortifications without a single seam in its rock. It included forges, warehouses, thousands of defenders, and its own fortified dock.

nʌn ə ðət wəd bi mʌtʃ jus əɡɛnst ən ɑɹmi ʌv sintʃæn wɪð deɪmeɪn ən ɹeɪkən.

None of that would be much use against an army of Seanchan with damane and raken.

kɹaʊdz laɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ ʌp tə ðə stoʊn vɝdʒ, ðə lɑɹdʒ oʊpən speɪs ðət sɝaʊndəd ðə stoʊn ɑn θɹi saɪdz. ɪts ə kɪlɪŋ fild, luz θɝɪn sɛd.

Crowds lined the street up to the Stone Verge, the large open space that surrounded the Stone on three sides. It's a killing field, Lews Therin said.

hɪɹ, ənʌðɝ kɹaʊd tʃɪɹd ɹænd. ðə ɡeɪts tə ðə stoʊn wɝ oʊpən, ən ə wɛlkəmɪŋ dɛləɡeɪʃən əweɪɾəd hɪm. dɑɹlɪn - wʌns ə haɪ lɔɹd, naʊ kɪŋ ə tɛɹ - sæɾ əstʃɹaɪɾ ə bɹɪljənt waɪt stæljən. ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɹænd baɪ ət list ə hɛd, ðə tɛɹən hæɾ ə ʃɔɹt blæk bɪɹɾ ən kloʊs-kɹɑp hɛɹ. hɪz pɹɑmənənt noʊz kɛpt ɪm fɹəm biɪŋ hænsəm, bʌt ɹænd hæd faʊn ɪm vɛɹi kin ə maɪn ən ʌv ɑnɝ. æftɝ ɔl, dɑɹlɪn hæɾ əpoʊzd ɹænd fɹəm ðə stɑɹt, ɹæðɝ ðən dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðoʊz u hæd heɪsən tə wɝʃəp hɪm. ə mæn huz əlidʒəns wɑz hɑɹd tə wɪn wɑz ɔfən wʌn huz əlidʒəns wəɾ ɔlsoʊ bi sɪkjʊɹ wən i wɑz aʊɾ ə jəɹ saɪt.

Here, another crowd cheered Rand. The gates to the Stone were open, and a welcoming delegation awaited him. Darlin - once a High Lord, now King of Tear - sat astride a brilliant white stallion. Shorter than Rand by at least a head, the Tairen had a short black beard and close-cropped hair. His prominent nose kept him from being handsome, but Rand had found him very keen of mind and of honor. After all, Darlin had opposed Rand from the start, rather than joining those who had hastened to worship him. A man whose allegiance was hard to win was often one whose allegiance would also be secure when he was out of your sight.

dɑɹlɪn baʊd tə ɹænd. peɪl-feɪs dɑbɹeɪn, dʒɹɛst ɪn ə blu koʊɾ ən waɪt tʃɹaʊzɝz, sæɾ əstʃɹaɪɾ ə ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə kɪŋ. hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz ənɹiɾəbəl, ðoʊ ɹænd səspɛktəɾ i wɑz stɪl dɪsəpɔɪntɪɾ ɪn biɪŋ sɛn fɹəm ɑɹæd dumən soʊ sun.

Darlin bowed to Rand. Pale-faced Dobraine, dressed in a blue coat and white trousers, sat astride a roan gelding beside the King. His expression was unreadable, though Rand suspected he was still disappointed in being sent from Arad Doman so soon.

laɪnz ə dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn stʊd bɪfɔɹ ðə wɔl, sɔɹdz hɛl bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, bɹɛstpleɪts ən ɹɪdʒ hɛlməts ʃaɪnd nɪɹ tə ɡloʊɪŋ. ðɛɹ pʌfi slivz wɝ stʃɹaɪpt wɪð blæk ən ɡoʊld, ən əbʌv əm weɪv ðə bænɝ ə tɛɹ, ə hæf-ɹɛd, hæf-ɡoʊl fil mɑɹkt wɪð θɹi sɪlvɝ kɹɛsəns.

Lines of Defenders of the Stone stood before the wall, swords held before them, breastplates and ridged helmets shined near to glowing. Their puffy sleeves were striped with black and gold, and above them waved the banner of Tear, a half-red, half-gold field marked with three silver crescents.

ɹænd kəd si ðət ðə skwɛɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔl wɑz bɝstɪŋ wɪð soʊlʒɝz, mɛni ɪn ðə kʌlɝz ə ðə dɪfɛndɝz, bʌt mɛni wɛɹɪŋ noʊ junəfɔɹm bɪɑn ə stʃɹæp ə ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊl taɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ ɑɹmz. ðoʊz wəd bi ðə nu ɹəkɹuts, ðə mɛn ɹænd hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd dɑɹlɪn tə ɡæðɝ.

Rand could see that the square inside the wall was bursting with soldiers, many in the colors of the Defenders, but many wearing no uniform beyond a strap of red and gold tied around their arms. Those would be the new recruits, the men Rand had ordered Darlin to gather.

ɪt wɑz ə dɪspleɪ tə pɹədus ɑ. əɹ pɝhæps tə stʃɹoʊk ə mænz pɹaɪd. ɹænd stɑp teɪdeɪʃɝ bɪfɔɹ dɑɹlɪn. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðə ɹustɝ wɪɹɑmɑn əkʌmpənid ðə kɪŋ, sɪɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs dʒʌs bɪhaɪn dɑɹlɪn. wɪɹɑmɑn wɑz soʊ lækɪŋ ɪn wɪts ðət ɹænd wəd bɛɹli hæv tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɪm tə wɝk ə fild ənsupɝvaɪzd, lɛɾ əloʊn kəmæn ə skwɑɾ ə tʃɹups. tʃɹu, ðə ʃɔɹt mæn wɑz bɹeɪv, bʌt ðət wɑz laɪkli oʊnli kəz i wɑz tu sloʊ ʌv θɔt tə kənsɪɾɝ moʊs deɪnʒɝz. əz ɔlweɪz, wɪɹɑmɑn lʊkt ivən mɔɹ ðə ful fəɹ ətɛmptɪŋ tə staɪl hɪmsɛlf əz ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ə bəfun; hɪz bɪɹd wɑz wækst, hɪz hɛɹ wɑz kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒd tə haɪd dʒʌs haʊ mʌtʃ i wɑz bɔldɪŋ ən ɪz kloʊðɪŋ wɑz ɹɪtʃ - ə koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz kʌɾ əz ɪf tə bi ə fil junəfɔɹm, bʌt noʊ mæn wəd wɛɹ sətʃ faɪn klɔθ ɪndə bæɾəl. noʊ mæn bʌt wɪɹɑmɑn.

It was a display to produce awe. Or perhaps to stroke a man's pride. Rand stopped Tai'daishar before Darlin. Unfortunately, the rooster Weiramon accompanied the King, sitting his horse just behind Darlin. Weiramon was so lacking in wits that Rand would barely have trusted him to work a field unsupervised, let alone command a squad of troops. True, the short man was brave, but that was likely only because he was too slow of thought to consider most dangers. As always, Weiramon looked even more the fool for attempting to style himself as anything other than a buffoon; his beard was waxed, his hair was carefully arranged to hide just how much he was balding and his clothing was rich - a coat and breeches cut as if to be a field uniform, but no man would wear such fine cloth into battle. No man but Weiramon.

aɪ laɪk hɪm, luz θɝɪn θɔt.

I like him, Lews Therin thought.

ɹænd stɑɹɾəd. jə doʊn laɪk ɛniwʌn!

Rand started. You don't like anyone!

hiz ɑnəst, luz θɝɪn ɹɪplaɪd, ðən læft. mɔɹ ðən aɪ æm, fəɹ sɝɾən! ə mæn dʌzn tʃuz tə bi ən ɪɾiət, bʌɾ i dʌz tʃuz tə bi lɔɪəl. wi kəd də mʌtʃ wɝs ðən əv ðɪs mæn əz ə fɑloʊɝ.
