He's honest, Lews Therin replied, then laughed. More than I am, for certain! A man doesn't choose to be an idiot, but he does choose to be loyal. We could do much worse than have this man as a follower.

ɹænd kɛpt ɪz tʌŋ. ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð ðə mædmæn wɑz pɔɪnləs. luz θɝɪn meɪd dɪsɪʒənz wɪθaʊt ɹizən. ət list i wɑzn hʌmɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən əɡɛn. ðət kəd bi dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ.

Rand kept his tongue. Arguing with the madman was pointless. Lews Therin made decisions without reason. At least he wasn't humming about a pretty woman again. That could be distracting.

dɑɹlɪn ən dɑbɹeɪn baʊd tə ɹænd, wɪɹɑmɑn mɪmɪkɪŋ ðɛm. ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz bɪhaɪn ðə kɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs. leɪɾi kæɹɑlin wɑz ə ɡɪvən; ðə slɛndɝ kɛɹhinɪn wɑz əz bjuɾəfəl əz ɹænd ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ə waɪɾ oʊpəl hʌŋ ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd, ðə ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn woʊvən ɪndə hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ. ɹænd hæd tə fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə lʊk əweɪ. ʃi lʊk tu mʌtʃ laɪk əɹ kʌzən, mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, luz θɝɪn stɑɹɾəd neɪmɪŋ ɔf ðə neɪmz ɑn ðə lɪst, mɔɪɹeɪn ət ðə fɔɹfɹʌnt.

Darlin and Dobraine bowed to Rand, Weiramon mimicking them. There were others behind the King, of course. Lady Caraline was a given; the slender Cairhienin was as beautiful as Rand remembered. A white opal hung on her forehead, the golden chain woven into her dark hair. Rand had to force himself to look away. She looked too much like her cousin, Moiraine. Sure enough, Lews Therin started naming off the names on the list, Moiraine at the forefront.

ɹænd stil hɪmsɛlf, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə dɛd mæn ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪn əz i stʌɾid ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɡɹup. ɔl ə ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ haɪ lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz ə tiɹ wɝ ðəɹ - ətɑp ðɛɹ oʊn maʊns.

Rand steeled himself, listening to the dead man in the back of his mind as he studied the rest of the group. All of the remaining High Lords and Ladies of Tear were there - atop their own mounts.

sɪmpɝɪŋ ænɑiɛlə sæɾ əɹ beɪ hɔɹs bɪsaɪd wɪɹɑmɑn. ən . . . wɑz ʃi wɛɹɪŋ ə hæŋkɝtʃɪf feɪvɝ bɛɹɪŋ ɪz kʌlɝz? ɹænd hæd θɔɾ əɹ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ dɪskɹɪməneɪɾɪŋ ðən ðæt. tʃɹiən hæɾ ə smaɪl ɑn ðət lʌmpi feɪs ə hɪz. ə pɪɾi ðəɾ i wɑz stɪl əlaɪv wən fɑɹ bɛɾɝ mɛn əmʌŋ ðə haɪ lɔɹdz hæd daɪd. sɪmɑn, ɪstændə, tidoʊzɪn, hɝn - ɔl fɔɹ hæɾ əpoʊzd ɹænd, liɾɪŋ ðə sidʒ əɡɛns ðə stoʊn. naʊ ðeɪ baʊd tə hɪm.

Simpering Anaiyella sat her bay horse beside Weiramon. And . . . was she wearing a handkerchief favor bearing his colors? Rand had thought her a little more discriminating than that. Torean had a smile on that lumpy face of his. A pity that he was still alive when far better men among the High Lords had died. Simaan, Estanda, Tedosian, Hearne - all four had opposed Rand, leading the siege against the Stone. Now they bowed to him.

ɑlɑnə wɑz ðɛɹ, tu. ɹænd dɪdn lʊk ət hɝ. ʃi wɑz sɑɹoʊfəl, hi kəd tɛl θɹu ðɛɹ bɑnd. əz wɛl ʃi ʃəd bi.

Alanna was there, too. Rand didn't look at her. She was sorrowful, he could tell through their bond. As well she should be.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," dɑɹlɪn sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, "θæŋk jə fəɹ sɛndɪŋ dɑbɹeɪn wɪð jəɹ wɪʃɪz." hɪz vɔɪs kənveɪɾ ɪz dɪsplɛʒɝ. hid ɹʌʃt tə ɡæðɝ ən ɑɹmi ət ɹændz ɝdʒən kəmænd, ən ðən ɹænd hæd fɔɹst ɪm tə də nʌθɪŋ fəɹ wiks. wɛl, ðə mɛn wəd bi ɡlæd fəɹ ði ɛkstʃɹə wiks ə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ sun.

"My Lord Dragon," Darlin said, straightening in his saddle, "thank you for sending Dobraine with your wishes." His voice conveyed his displeasure. He'd rushed to gather an army at Rand's urgent command, and then Rand had forced him to do nothing for weeks. Well, the men would be glad for the extra weeks of training soon.

"ði ɑɹmi ɪz ɹɛɾi," dɑɹlɪn kəntɪnjud, hɛzɪɾənt. "wi ɑɹ pɹipɛɹd tə liv fəɹ ɑɹæd dumən."

"The army is ready," Darlin continued, hesitant. "We are prepared to leave for Arad Doman."

ɹænd nɑɾəd. hiɾ ɝɪdʒənəli ɪntɛndəd tə sɛt dɑɹlɪn ɪn ɑɹæd dumən soʊ hi kəd pʊl il ən æʃəmən aʊt fəɹ pleɪsmən ɛlswɛɹ. hi tɝnd, ɡlænsɪŋ bæk ət ðə kɹaʊdz, æbsənli ɹilaɪzɪŋ waɪ ðəɹ wɝ soʊ mɛni fɔɹənɝz əmʌŋ ðɛm. moʊst ə ðə næʃənəlz hæd bɪn ɹɪkɹuɾɪd fəɹ ði ɑɹmi, ən naʊ stʊɾ ɪn ɹæŋks ɪnsaɪd ðə stoʊn.

Rand nodded. He'd originally intended to set Darlin in Arad Doman so he could pull Aiel and Asha'man out for placement elsewhere. He turned, glancing back at the crowds, absently realizing why there were so many foreigners among them. Most of the nationals had been recruited for the army, and now stood in ranks inside the Stone.

pɝhæps ðə pipəl ɪn ðə skwɛɹ ən ɑn ðə stʃɹits hædn bɪn ðəɹ tə tʃɪɹ ɹændz ɝaɪvəl.

Perhaps the people in the square and on the streets hadn't been there to cheer Rand's arrival.

pɝhæps ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ tʃɪɹɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ ɑɹmiz ɔf tə vɪktɝi.

Perhaps they thought they were cheering their departing armies off to victory.

"ju hæv dʌn wɛl, kɪŋ dɑɹlɪn," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪts əbaʊt taɪm sʌmwʌn ɪn tɛɹ lɝn tə oʊbeɪ ɔɹɾɝz. aɪ noʊ jəɹ mɛn ɑɹ ɪmpeɪʃənt, bʌt ðəl əv tə weɪɾ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm lɔŋɡɝ. meɪk ɹumz fəɹ mi ɪn ðə stoʊn ən si tə kɔɹɾɝɪŋ bæʃɪɹz soʊlʒɝz ən ði il."

"You have done well, King Darlin," Rand said. "It's about time someone in Tear learned to obey orders. I know your men are impatient, but they will have to wait a short time longer. Make rooms for me in the Stone and see to quartering Bashere's soldiers and the Aiel."

dɑɹlɪnz kənfjuʒən dipənd. "vɛɹi wɛl. ɑɹ wi nɑt niɾəd ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, ðɛn?"

Darlin's confusion deepened. "Very well. Are we not needed in Arad Doman, then?"

"wʌɾ ɑɹæd dumən nidz, noʊbɑdi kən ɡɪv," ɹænd sɛd. "jɔɹ fɔɹsɪz wɪl bi kʌmɪŋ wɪð mi."

"What Arad Doman needs, nobody can give," Rand said. "Your forces will be coming with me."

"ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd. ən . . . wɛɹ wɪl wi bi mɑɹtʃɪŋ?"

"Of course, my Lord. And . . . where will we be marching?"

"tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl."

"To Shayol Ghul."

tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾiθɹi

CHAPTER 43

sil tə ðə fleɪm ɛɡwin sæt kwaɪətli ɪn əɹ tɛnt, hænz ɪn əɹ læp. ʃi kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ ʃɑk, hɝ bɝnɪŋ æŋɡɝ ən əɹ ɪnkɹədulɪɾi.

Sealed to the Flame Egwene sat quietly in her tent, hands in her lap. She controlled her shock, her burning anger and her incredulity.

plʌmp, pɹɪɾi tʃɛsə sæt saɪlənli ɑn ə kʊʃən ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, soʊɪŋ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ðə hɛm ʌv wʌn ʌv ɛɡwinz dʒɹɛsəz, lʊkɪŋ əz kɑntɛn əz ə pɝsən kəd bi, naʊ ðəɾ əɹ mɪstʃɹəs hæd ɹɪtɝnd. ðə tɛnt wɑz sɪkluɾɪd, sɛɾ ɪn ɪts oʊn ɡɹoʊv wɪðɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp. ɛɡwin hæɾ əlaʊd noʊ ətɛndəns bɪsaɪdz tʃɛsə ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. ʃi hæɾ ivən tɝn əweɪ sɪuən, hu hæɾ əndaʊɾɪdli kʌm tə ɔfɝ səm kaɪndə əpɑlədʒi. ɛɡwin niɾəd taɪm tə θɪŋk, tə pɹipɛɹ, tə dil wɪð əɹ feɪljɝ.

Plump, pretty Chesa sat silently on a cushion in the corner, sewing embroidery on the hem of one of Egwene's dresses, looking as content as a person could be, now that her mistress had returned. The tent was secluded, set in its own grove within the Aes Sedai camp. Egwene had allowed no attendants besides Chesa this morning. She had even turned away Siuan, who had undoubtedly come to offer some kind of apology. Egwene needed time to think, to prepare, to deal with her failure.

ən ɪt wɑz ə feɪljɝ. jɛs, ɪt hæd bɪn fɔɹst ɑn əɹ baɪ ʌðɝz, bʌt ðoʊz ʌðɝz wɝ əɹ fɑloʊɝz ən fɹɛnz. ðeɪ wəd noʊ hɝ æŋɡɝ fəɹ ðɛɹ pɑɹɾ ɪn ðɪs fiæskoʊ. bʌt fɝst ʃi niɾəd tə lʊk ɪnwɝd, tə dʒʌdʒ wʌt ʃi ʃʊɾə dʌn bɛɾɝ.

And it was a failure. Yes, it had been forced on her by others, but those others were her followers and friends. They would know her anger for their part in this fiasco. But first she needed to look inward, to judge what she should have done better.

ʃi sæɾ ɪn əɹ wʊɾən tʃɛɹ, haɪ-bækt, wɪð skɹɑlwɝk pæɾɝnz əkɹɔs ði ɑɹmɹɛsts. hɝ tɛnt wɑz əz ʃi hæd lɛft ɪt, dɛsk ɔɹɾɝli, blæŋkəts foʊldəd, pɪloʊz stækt ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ɑbviəsli kɛp dʌstɪd baɪ tʃɛsə. laɪk ə mjuziəm juz tə ɪnstʃɹʌk tʃɪlʒɹən ə deɪz pæst.

She sat in her wooden chair, high-backed, with scrollwork patterns across the armrests. Her tent was as she had left it, desk orderly, blankets folded, pillows stacked in the corner, obviously kept dusted by Chesa. Like a museum used to instruct children of days past.

ɛɡwin hæd bɪn əz fɔɹsfəl əz pɑsəbəl wɪð sɪuən dʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ miɾɪŋz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ən jɛt ðeɪd stɪl kʌm əɡɛnst əɹ wɪʃɪz. pɝhæps ʃi hæd bɪn tu sikɹəɾɪv. ɪt wɑz ə deɪnʒɝ -  sikɹəsi. ɪt wɑz wʌt hæd pʊl daʊn sɪuən. ðə wʊmənz taɪm əz hɛɾ ə ðə blu ədʒɑz aɪz-ænd- ɪɹz hæd tɔɾ əɹ tə bi pɑɹsəmoʊniəs wɪð ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, doʊlɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt laɪk ə stɪnʒi ɛmplɔɪɝ ɑn peɪdeɪ. ɪf ði ʌðɝz hæd noʊn ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə sɪuənz wɝk, pɝhæps ðeɪ wʊdn əv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə wɝk əɡɛns hɝ.

Egwene had been as forceful as possible with Siuan during their meetings in Tel'aran'rhiod, and yet they'd still come against her wishes. Perhaps she had been too secretive. It was a danger -  secrecy. It was what had pulled down Siuan. The woman's time as head of the Blue Ajah's eyes-and- ears had taught her to be parsimonious with information, doling it out like a stingy employer on payday. If the others had known the importance of Siuan's work, perhaps they wouldn't have decided to work against her.

ɛɡwin ɹæn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əlɔŋ ðə smuð, taɪtli woʊvən paʊtʃ ʃi wɔɹ taɪd tə hɝ bɛlt. ɪnsaɪd wɑz ə lɔŋ, θɪn aɪɾəm, ɹitʃɹiv sikɹɪtli fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɝliɝ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ.

Egwene ran her fingers along the smooth, tightly woven pouch she wore tied to her belt. Inside was a long, thin item, retrieved secretly from the White Tower earlier in the morning.

hæd ʃi fɔlən ɪndə ðə seɪm tʃɹæp əz sɪuən? ɪt wɑz ə deɪnʒɝ. ʃi hæd bɪn tʃɹeɪn baɪ sɪuən, æftɝ ɔl. ɪf ɛɡwin hæɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪn mɔɹ dɪteɪl haʊ wɛl əɹ wɝk ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, wəd ði ʌðɝz əv steɪd ðɛɹ hænz?

Had she fallen into the same trap as Siuan? It was a danger. She had been trained by Siuan, after all. If Egwene had explained in more detail how well her work in the White Tower was going, would the others have stayed their hands?

ɪt wɑz ə dɪfəkəlt laɪn tə wɔk. ðəɹ wɝ mɛni sikɹəts ðəɾ ən æmɪɝlɪn hæd tə hoʊld. tə bi tʃɹænspɛɹənt wəd bi tə luz əɹ ɛdʒ ʌv əθɔɹəɾi. bʌt wɪð sɪuən hɝsɛlf, ɛɡwin ʃʊɾə bɪn mɔɹ fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ. ðə wʊmən wɑz tu əkʌstəm tə teɪkɪŋ ækʃən ɑn əɹ oʊn. ðə weɪ ʃi hæd kɛp ðət dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil əɡɛns ðə hɔlz nɑlədʒ ən wɪʃɪz wɑz ən ɪndəkeɪʃən ə ðæt. jɛɾ ɛɡwin hæɾ əpɹuvd ə ðæt, ʌnkɑnʃəsli ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ sɪuən tə dɪfaɪ əθɔɹəɾi.

It was a difficult line to walk. There were many secrets that an Amyrlin had to hold. To be transparent would be to lose her edge of authority. But with Siuan herself, Egwene should have been more forthcoming. The woman was too accustomed to taking action on her own. The way she had kept that dream ter'angreal against the Hall's knowledge and wishes was an indication of that. Yet Egwene had approved of that, unconsciously encouraging Siuan to defy authority.

jɛs, ɛɡwin hæd meɪd mɪsteɪks. ʃi kəd nɑt leɪ ɔl ðə bleɪm ɑn sɪuən, bɹaɪn ən ɡɔɪn. ʃi hæd laɪkli meɪɾ ʌðɝ mɪsteɪks əz wɛl; ʃi wəd nid tə lʊk əɾ əɹ oʊn ækʃənz ɪn mɔɹ dɪteɪl leɪɾɝ.

Yes, Egwene had made mistakes. She could not lay all the blame on Siuan, Bryne and Gawyn. She had likely made other mistakes as well; she would need to look at her own actions in more detail later.

fəɹ naʊ, ʃi tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɹɑbləm. dɪzæstɝ hæd stʃɹʌk. ʃid bɪn pʊl fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə səksɛs. wʌt wɑz tə bi dʌn? ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ ʌp ən peɪs ɪn θɔt. tə peɪs wɑz tə ʃoʊ nɝvəsnəs əɹ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, ən ʃi hæd tə lɝn tə bi ɹɪzɝvd əɾ ɔl taɪmz, lɛst ʃi ənwɪɾɪŋli fɔl ɪndə bæd hæbəts. soʊ ʃi ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd, ɑɹmz ɑn ðə hæn ɹɛsts, wɛɹɪŋ ə faɪn sɪlkən ɡaʊn ʌv ɡɹin wɪð jɛloʊ pæɾɝnz ɑn ðə bɑɾəs.

For now, she turned her attention to a greater problem. Disaster had struck. She'd been pulled from the White Tower on the brink of success. What was to be done? She did not get up and pace in thought. To pace was to show nervousness or frustration, and she had to learn to be reserved at all times, lest she unwittingly fall into bad habits. So she remained seated, arms on the hand rests, wearing a fine silken gown of green with yellow patterns on the bodice.

haʊ ɑɾ ɪt fɛl tə bi ɪn ðət skɝt. haʊ ɹɔŋ. hɝ waɪt dʒɹɛsəz, ðoʊ fɔɹst əpɑn hɝ, hæd bɪkʌm sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə sɪmbəl ə dɪfaɪəns. tə tʃeɪnʒ naʊ mɛn ən ɛn tə hɝ stʃɹaɪk. ʃi wɑz taɪɝd, ɪmoʊʃnəli ən fɪzɪkəli, fɹəm ðə naɪts bæɾəl. bʌt ʃi kʊdnt ɡɪv ɪn tə ðæt. ðɪs wʊdn bi hɝ fɝs nɪɹ-slipləs naɪt bɪfɔɹ ə vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt deɪ ʌv dɪsɪʒənz ən pɹɑbləmz.

How odd it felt to be in that skirt. How wrong. Her white dresses, though forced upon her, had become something of a symbol of defiance. To change now meant an end to her strike. She was tired, emotionally and physically, from the night's battle. But she couldn't give in to that. This wouldn't be her first near-sleepless night before a very important day of decisions and problems.

ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf tæpɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmɹɛst ən fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə stɑp.

She found herself tapping her armrest and forced herself to stop.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ ʃi kəd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz ə nɑvəs naʊ. hɝ dɪfaɪəns hæd wɝkt oʊnli kəz ʃi hæd bɪn ə kæptɪv æmɪɝlɪn. ɪf ʃi wɛn bæk wɪlɪŋli, ʃi wəd bi sin əz səbsɝviənt, əɹ əz ɛɹəɡənt. bɪsaɪdz, ɪleɪɾə wəd sɝɾənli hæv əɹ ɛksəkjuɾəd ðɪs taɪm.

There was no way she could return to the White Tower as a novice now. Her defiance had worked only because she had been a captive Amyrlin. If she went back willingly, she would be seen as subservient, or as arrogant. Besides, Elaida would certainly have her executed this time.

ən soʊ ʃi wɑz stʌk, dʒʌst əz ʃi hæd bɪn wən ʃid fɝs bɪn teɪkən baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝz eɪdʒəns. ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. ʃid wʌns θɔt, mɪsteɪkənli, ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn wʊdn bi soʊ izəli tɔst əbaʊt baɪ ɹændəm twɪsts ɪn ðə pæɾɝn. ʃi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls spɛn ðɛɹ deɪz ɹiæktɪŋ, bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz ə wʊmən ʌv ækʃən!

And so she was stuck, just as she had been when she'd first been taken by the White Tower's agents. She gritted her teeth. She'd once thought, mistakenly, that the Amyrlin wouldn't be so easily tossed about by random twists in the Pattern. She was supposed to be in control. Everyone else spent their days reacting, but the Amyrlin was a woman of action!

ʃi wɑz ɹilaɪzɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ðət biɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑzn dɪfɹənt. laɪf wɑz ə tɛmpəst, wɛðɝ jə wɝ ə mɪlkmeɪɾ əɹ ə kwin. ðə kwinz wɝ sɪmpli bɛɾɝ ət pɹədʒɛktɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðət stɔɹm. ɪf ɛɡwin lʊk laɪk ə stætʃu ʌnəfɛktɪd baɪ ðə wɪnz, ɪt wɑz æktʃəli  kəz ʃi sɔ haʊ tə bɛnd wɪð ðoʊz wɪnz. ðət ɡeɪv ði ɪluʒən ə kəntʃɹoʊl.

She was realizing more and more that being the Amyrlin wasn't different. Life was a tempest, whether you were a milkmaid or a queen. The queens were simply better at projecting control in the middle of that storm. If Egwene looked like a statue unaffected by the winds, it was actually because she saw how to bend with those winds. That gave the illusion of control.

noʊ. ɪt wɑz nɑt dʒʌst ən ɪluʒən. ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪɾ əv mɔɹ kəntʃɹoʊl, ɪf oʊnli kəz ʃi kəntʃɹoʊl hɝsɛlf ən kɛp ðə tɛmpəst aʊtsaɪd hɝ. ʃi sweɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə nidz ə ðə moʊmənt, bʌɾ əɹ ækʃənz wɝ wɛl-kənsɪɾɝd. ʃi hæd tə bi əz lɑdʒɪkəl əz ə waɪt, əz θɔtfəl əz ə bɹaʊn, əz pæʃənəɾ əz ə blu, əz dɪsaɪsɪv əz ə ɡɹin, əz mɝsɪfəl əz ə jɛloʊ, əz dɪpləmæɾɪk əz ə ɡɹeɪ. ən jɛs, əz vɛnʒfəl əz ə ɹɛd, wən nɛsəsɛɹi.

No. It was not just an illusion. The Amyrlin did have more control, if only because she controlled herself and kept the tempest outside her. She swayed before the needs of the moment, but her actions were well-considered. She had to be as logical as a White, as thoughtful as a Brown, as passionate as a Blue, as decisive as a Green, as merciful as a Yellow, as diplomatic as a Gray. And yes, as vengeful as a Red, when necessary.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz ə nɑvəs, ən ʃi kʊdnt weɪt fəɹ nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz.

There was no returning to the White Tower as a novice, and she couldn't wait for negotiations.

nɑt wɪð ðə sintʃæn boʊld ɪnʌf tə stʃɹaɪk ðə waɪt taʊɝ, nɑt wɪð ɹænd kəmplitli ənwɑtʃt, nɑt wɪð ðə wɝld ɪn keɪɑs ən ðə ʃædoʊ ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪts fɔɹsɪz fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. ðət lɛft əɹ wɪð ə dɪfəkəl dɪsɪʒən. ʃi hæɾ ə fɹɛʃ ɑɹmi ʌv fɪfti θaʊzən tʃɹups, ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd sʌfɝɾ ən ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl bloʊ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd bi ɪɡzɔstəd, ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd bɹoʊkən ən wundəd.

Not with the Seanchan bold enough to strike the White Tower, not with Rand completely unwatched, not with the world in chaos and the Shadow gathering its forces for the Last Battle. That left her with a difficult decision. She had a fresh army of fifty thousand troops, and the White Tower had suffered an incredible blow. The Aes Sedai would be exhausted, the Tower Guard broken and wounded.

ɪn ə fju deɪz' taɪm, ðə hilɪŋz wəd bi fɪnɪʃt ən ðə wɪmən ɹɛstəd. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ ɪf ɪleɪɾə hæd sɝvaɪv ði ətæk əɹ nɑt, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd tə əsum ʃi wɑz stɪl ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. ðət ɡeɪv ɛɡwin ə vɛɹi nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊ fəɹ ækʃən.

In a few days' time, the Healings would be finished and the women rested. She didn't know if Elaida had survived the attack or not, but Egwene had to assume she was still in control. That gave Egwene a very narrow window for action.

ʃi nu wʌt ði oʊnli ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən wɑz. ʃi dɪdn əv taɪm tə weɪt fəɹ ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə meɪk ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən, ʃi wəɾ əv tə fɔɹs əm tə æksɛp hɝ.

She knew what the only right decision was. She didn't have time to wait for the sisters in the White Tower to make the right decision, she would have to force them to accept her.

ʃi hoʊp ðət hɪstɝi wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli fɝɡɪv hɝ.

She hoped that history would eventually forgive her.

ʃi ɹoʊz, θɹu oʊpən ðə flæps ə hɝ tɛnt, ən stɑp dɛd. ə mæn wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ.

She rose, threw open the flaps of her tent, and stopped dead. A man was sitting on the ground directly in front of her.

ɡɔɪn skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit, ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz hænsəm əz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd. hi wɑzn bjuɾəfəl, laɪk ɪz hæf-bɹʌðɝ. ɡɔɪn wɑz mɔɹ sɑləd, mɔɹ ɹil. stʃɹaɪkɪŋli, ðət naʊ meɪɾ ɪm mɔɹ ətʃɹæktɪv tə ɛɡwin ðən ɡɑləd. ɡɑləd wɑz laɪk ə biɪŋ fɹəm bɪɑn ɹiæləɾi, ə fɪɡjɝ ə lɛdʒənz ən stɔɹiz. hi wɑz laɪk ə ɡlæs stætʃu tə bi pleɪst ɑn ə teɪbəl fəɹ ædmɝeɪʃən, bʌt nɛvɝ tʌtʃt.

Gawyn scrambled to his feet, every bit as handsome as she remembered. He wasn't beautiful, like his half-brother. Gawyn was more solid, more real. Strikingly, that now made him more attractive to Egwene than Galad. Galad was like a being from beyond reality, a figure of legends and stories. He was like a glass statue to be placed on a table for admiration, but never touched.

ɡɔɪn wɑz dɪfɹənt. hænsəm, wɪð ðət bɹɪljən ɹɛɾɪʃ ɡoʊl hɛɹ ən ðoʊz tɛndɝ aɪz.

Gawyn was different. Handsome, with that brilliant reddish gold hair and those tender eyes.

waɪl ɡɑləd nɛvɝ wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ, ɡɔɪnz kənsɝn meɪɾ ɪm dʒɛnjəwən. əz dɪɾ ɪz əbɪləɾi tə meɪk mɪsteɪks, ənfɔɹtʃənətli.

While Galad never worried about anything, Gawyn's concern made him genuine. As did his ability to make mistakes, unfortunately.

"ɛɡwin," hi sɛd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən dʌstɪŋ ɔf ɪz tʃɹaʊzɝ lɛɡz. laɪt! hæɾ i slɛp ðəɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ tɛnt? ðə sʌn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi hæfweɪ tə ɪts zinəθ. ðə mæn ʃʊɾə ɡɔn tə teɪk səm ɹɛst!

"Egwene," he said, righting his sword and dusting off his trouser legs. Light! Had he slept there in front of her tent? The sun was already halfway to its zenith. The man should have gone to take some rest!

ɛɡwin skwɛltʃt əɹ kənsɝn ən wɝi fəɹ hɪm. ɪt wɑz nɑt taɪm tə bi ə lʌvisɪk ɡɝl. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə bi æmɪɝlɪn. "ɡɔɪn," ʃi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hænd, stɑpɪŋ ɪm əz i stɛp təwɔɹd hɝ. "aɪ hævən bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt tə də wɪð ju. ʌðɝ mæɾɝz dɪmæn maɪ ətɛnʃən. hæz ðə hɔl ɡæðɝd, əz aɪ ɹɪkwɛstɪd?"

Egwene squelched her concern and worry for him. It was not time to be a lovesick girl. It was time to be Amyrlin. "Gawyn," she said, raising a hand, stopping him as he stepped toward her. "I haven't begun to think about what to do with you. Other matters demand my attention. Has the Hall gathered, as I requested?"

"aɪ θɪŋk soʊ," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə sɛntɝ ə kæmp. ʃi kəd dʒʌs bɛɹli meɪk aʊt ðə lɑɹdʒ ɡæðɝɪŋ tɛn ə ðə hɔl θɹu ðə skɹʌb tʃɹiz.

"I think so," he said, turning to glance toward the center of camp. She could just barely make out the large gathering tent of the Hall through the scrub trees.

"ðɛn aɪ mʌst əpɪɹ bɪfɔɹ ðɛm," ɛɡwin sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃi bɪɡæn tə wɔk fɔɹwɝd.

"Then I must appear before them," Egwene said, taking a deep breath. She began to walk forward.

"noʊ," ɡɔɪn sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. "ɛɡwin, wi nid tə tɔk."

"No," Gawyn said, stepping in front of her. "Egwene, we need to talk."

"leɪɾɝ."

"Later."

"noʊ, nɑt leɪɾɝ, bɝn ɪt! aɪv weɪɾəd mʌnθs. aɪ nid tə noʊ haʊ wi stænd. aɪ nid tə noʊ ɪf ju  - "

"No, not later, burn it! I've waited months. I need to know how we stand. I need to know if you  - "

"stɑp!" ʃi sɛd.

"Stop!" she said.

hi fɹoʊz. ʃi wəd nɑt bi teɪkən ɪn baɪ ðoʊz aɪz, bɝn hɪm! nɑt ɹaɪt naʊ. "aɪ sɛd ðəɾ aɪ hædn sɔɹɾɪd θɹu maɪ filɪŋz jɛt," ʃi sɛd kuli, "æn aɪ mɛn ɪt."

He froze. She would not be taken in by those eyes, burn him! Not right now. "I said that I hadn't sorted through my feelings yet," she said coolly, "and I meant it."

hi sɛɾ ɪz dʒɔ. "aɪ doʊn bɪliv ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑmnəs, ɛɡwin," hi sɛd. "nɑt wən jəɹ aɪz ɑɹ soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ tʃɹuθfəl. aɪv sækɹəfaɪst - "

He set his jaw. "I don't believe that Aes Sedai calmness, Egwene," he said. "Not when your eyes are so much more truthful. I've sacrificed - "

"juv sækɹəfaɪst?" ɛɡwin ɪntɝʌptɪd, lɛɾɪŋ ə lɪɾəl æŋɡɝ ʃoʊ. "wʌɾ əbaʊt wʌɾ aɪ sækɹəfaɪs tə ɹibɪl ðə waɪt taʊɝ? sækɹəfaɪsɪz ðət jə ʌndɝmaɪn baɪ æktɪŋ əɡɛns maɪ ɪkspɹɛs wɪʃɪz? dɪd sɪuən nɑt tɛl jə ðəɾ aɪ hæd fɔɹbɪɾən ə ɹɛskju?"

"You've sacrificed?" Egwene interrupted, letting a little anger show. "What about what I sacrificed to rebuild the White Tower? Sacrifices that you undermined by acting against my express wishes? Did Siuan not tell you that I had forbidden a rescue?"

"ʃi dɪd," hi sɛd stɪfli. "bʌt wi wɝ wɝiɾ əbaʊt ju!"

"She did," he said stiffly. "But we were worried about you!"

"wɛl, ðət wɝi wɑz ðə sækɹəfaɪs aɪ dɪmændəd, ɡɔɪn," ʃi sɛd, ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd. "doʊn jə si wʌɾ ə dɪstʃɹʌs juv ʃoʊn mi? haʊ kən aɪ tʃɹʌs jə ɪf jəl dɪsəbeɪ mi ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə fil mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl?"

"Well, that worry was the sacrifice I demanded, Gawyn," she said, exasperated. "Don't you see what a distrust you have shown me? How can I trust you if you will disobey me in order to feel more comfortable?"

ɡɔɪn dɪdn lʊk əʃeɪmd; hi dʒʌs lʊk pɝtɝbd. ðət wɑz æktʃəli  ə ɡʊd saɪn - əz æmɪɝlɪn, ʃi niɾəd ə mæn u wəd spik ɪz maɪnd. ɪn pɹaɪvət. bʌɾ ɪn pʌblɪk ʃid nid sʌmwʌn u səpɔɹɾəd hɝ. kʊdn i si ðæt?

Gawyn didn't look ashamed; he just looked perturbed. That was actually a good sign - as Amyrlin, she needed a man who would speak his mind. In private. But in public she'd need someone who supported her. Couldn't he see that?

"ju lʌv mi, ɛɡwin," hi sɛd stʌbɝnli. "aɪ kən si ɪt."

"You love me, Egwene," he said stubbornly. "I can see it."

"ɛɡwin ðə wʊmən lʌvz ju," ʃi sɛd. "bʌɾ ɛɡwin ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz fjʊɹiəs wɪð ju. ɡɔɪn, ɪf jud bi wɪð mi, juv tə bi wɪð boʊθ ðə wʊmən ən ði æmɪɝlɪn. aɪ wəɾ ɪkspɛk jə - ə mæn u wɑz tʃɹeɪn tə bi fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd - tə ʌndɝstæn ðət dɪstɪŋkʃən."

"Egwene the woman loves you," she said. "But Egwene the Amyrlin is furious with you. Gawyn, if you'd be with me, you have to be with both the woman and the Amyrlin. I would expect you - a man who was trained to be First Prince of the Sword - to understand that distinction."

ɡɔɪn lʊkt əweɪ.

Gawyn looked away.

"ju doʊn bɪliv ɪt, də ju?" ʃi æskt.

"You don't believe it, do you?" she asked.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

"ðæɾ aɪm æmɪɝlɪn," ʃi sɛd. "ju doʊn æksɛp maɪ taɪɾəl."

"That I'm Amyrlin," she said. "You don't accept my title."

"aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə," hi sɛɾ əz i lʊk bæk ət hɝ. "bʌt blʌɾi æʃəz, ɛɡwin. wən wi pɑɹɾəd jə wɝ dʒʌst ən æksɛptɪd, ən ðət wɑzn soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. naʊ ðeɪv neɪm jə æmɪɝlɪn? aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt tə θɪŋk."

"I'm trying to," he said as he looked back at her. "But bloody ashes, Egwene. When we parted you were just an Accepted, and that wasn't so long ago. Now they've named you Amyrlin? I don't know what to think."

"æn jə kæn si haʊ jəɹ ənsɝɾənti ʌndɝmaɪnz ɛniθɪŋ wi kəɾ əv təɡɛðɝ?"

"And you can't see how your uncertainty undermines anything we could have together?"

"aɪ kən tʃeɪnʒ. bʌt juv tə hɛlp mi."

"I can change. But you have to help me."

"wɪtʃ ɪz waɪ aɪ wɑntəd tə tɔk leɪɾɝ," ʃi sɛd. "ɑɹ jə gɑnə lemi pæs?"

"Which is why I wanted to talk later," she said. "Are you going to let me pass?"

hi stɛpt əsaɪd wɪð ɑbviəs ɹɪlʌktəns. "wɝ nɑt fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðɪs tɔk," hi wɔɹnd. "aɪv faɪnəli meɪɾ ʌp maɪ maɪn əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ, ən aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə stɑp tʃeɪsɪŋ ɪɾ əntɪl aɪ hæv ɪt."

He stepped aside with obvious reluctance. "We're not finished with this talk," he warned. "I've finally made up my mind about something, and I don't intend to stop chasing it until I have it."

"faɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd, pæsɪŋ hɪm. "aɪ kæn θɪŋk əbaʊt ðət naʊ. aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ ɔɹɾɝ pipəl aɪ kɛɹ əbaʊt tə slɔɾɝ ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ə pipəl aɪ kɛɹ əbaʊt."

"Fine," Egwene said, passing him. "I can't think about that now. I have to go order people I care about to slaughter another group of people I care about."

"jul də ɪt, ðɛn?" ɡɔɪn sɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. "ðɛɹz spɛkjəleɪʃən ɪn kæmp; aɪ hɝɾ ɪt ðoʊ aɪ bɛɹli lɛf ðɪs pleɪs ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ. səm θɪŋk jəl kəmæn bɹaɪn tə əsɔl ðə sɪɾi."

"You'll do it, then?" Gawyn said from behind. "There's speculation in camp; I heard it though I barely left this place all morning. Some think you'll command Bryne to assault the city."

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

She hesitated.

"ɪt wəd bi ə ʃeɪm ɪf ɪt hæpənd," hi sɛd. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ ə wɪɾ əbaʊt tɑɹ vəlɑn, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪt wəd də tə jə tə ətæk ɪt."

"It would be a shame if it happened," he said. "I don't care a whit about Tar Valon, but I think I know what it would do to you to attack it."

ʃi tɝn bæk tə hɪm. "aɪ wɪl də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn, ɡɔɪn," ʃi sɛd, miɾɪŋ ɪz aɪz. "fɔɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ivən ɪf ɪts peɪnfəl. ivən ɪf ɪt tɪɹz mi əpɑɹɾ ɪnsaɪd. əl də ɪɾ ɪf ɪt nidz tə bi dʌn. ɔlweɪz."

She turned back to him. "I will do what must be done, Gawyn," she said, meeting his eyes. "For the good of the Aes Sedai and the White Tower. Even if it is painful. Even if it tears me apart inside. I will do it if it needs to be done. Always."

hi nɑɾəd sloʊli. ʃi hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə pəvɪljən ət ðə sɛntɝ ə kæmp.

He nodded slowly. She headed for the pavilion at the center of camp.

"ðɪs wɑz jəɹ fɔlt, dʒɛsi," ædlɔɹnə sɛd. hɝ aɪz wɝ stɪl ɹɛd; ʃid lɔst ə wɔɹɾɝ ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə mɛni. bʌt ʃi wɑz ɔlsoʊ tʌf əz ə fɛɹəl haʊnd, ən wɑz ɑbviəsli dɪtɝmənd nɑt tə lɛɾ əɹ peɪn ʃoʊ.

"This was your fault, Jesse," Adelorna said. Her eyes were still red; she'd lost a Warder the night before. She was one of many. But she was also tough as a feral hound, and was obviously determined not to let her pain show.

dʒɛsi biləl wɔɹmd əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ kʌp ʌv ɡusbɛɹi ti, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə lɛt hɝsɛlf bi ɡoʊɾɪd.

Jesse Bilal warmed her hands on her cup of gooseberry tea, refusing to let herself be goaded.

ædlɔɹnəz kwɛstʃən hæd bɪn ɪnɛvəɾəbəl. ən pɝhæps dʒɛsi dɪzɝv ðə ɹɛpɹəmænd. ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪ ɔl dɪzɝvd ɪt, ɪn wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. ɪksɛpt pɝhæps fəɹ tsutɑmə, hu hædn bɪn ən ədʒɑ hɛɾ ət ðə taɪm. ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv waɪ ðə wʊmən hædn bɪn ɪnvaɪɾəd tə ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ miɾɪŋ. ðæt, ən ðə fæk ðət ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ wɑzn ɪn ɡʊd feɪvɝ wɪð ði ʌðɝz ət ðə moʊmənt.

Adelorna's question had been inevitable. And perhaps Jesse deserved the reprimand. Of course, they all deserved it, in one way or another. Except perhaps for Tsutama, who hadn't been an Ajah head at the time. That was part of why the woman hadn't been invited to this particular meeting. That, and the fact that the Red Ajah wasn't in good favor with the others at the moment.

ðə smɔl, kɹæmpt ɹum wɑz bɛɹli lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf fəɹ faɪv tʃɛɹz ən ðə smɔl pɑtbɛlid stoʊv ət ðə wɔl, ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ ə kɑm wɔɹmθ. ðəɹ wɑzn ɹum fəɹ ə teɪbəl, lɛɾ əloʊn ə hɑɹθ. dʒʌst ɪnʌf speɪs fəɹ faɪv wɪmən. ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wɪmən ɪn ðə wɝld. ən ðə faɪv moʊs fulɪʃ, ɪt simd.

The small, cramped room was barely large enough for five chairs and the small potbellied stove at the wall, radiating a calm warmth. There wasn't room for a table, let alone a hearth. Just enough space for five women. The most powerful women in the world. And the five most foolish, it seemed.

ðeɪ wɝ ə sɑɹi sɪstɝhʊd ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ðə mɔɹnɪŋ fɑloʊɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst dɪzæstɝ ɪn ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ. dʒɛsi ɡlænst ət ðə wʊmən bɪsaɪd hɝ. fɛɹən nhɝən - fɝst ɹizənɝ ə ðə waɪt - wɑz ə smɔl, staʊt wʊmən hu, ɑdli ɪn ə waɪt, ɔfən simd mɔɹ tɛmpɝ ðən lɑdʒɪk.

They were a sorry sisterhood this morning, the morning following the greatest disaster in the history of the White Tower. Jesse glanced at the woman beside her. Ferane Neheran - First Reasoner of the White - was a small, stout woman who, oddly in a White, often seemed more temper than logic.

tədeɪ wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz taɪmz: ʃi sæt skaʊlɪŋ, hɝ ɑɹmz foʊldəd. ʃid ɹəfjuzd ə kʌp ə ti.

Today was one of those times: she sat scowling, her arms folded. She'd refused a cup of tea.

nɛks tə hɝ wɑz swænə dʒɹeɪɡənd, fɝst wivɝ ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ. ʃi wɑz ə bifi θɪŋ wɪð ə θɹʌstɪŋ tʃɪn ðət mætʃt əɹ ənjildɪŋ dɪminɝ. ædlɔɹnə, ðə wʌn tə meɪk ði ækjəzeɪʃən əɡɛns dʒɛsi, wɑz bɪsaɪd hɝ. hu kəd bleɪm ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl fəɹ əɹ spaɪtfəlnəs? ʃi hu hæd bɪn bɝtʃt baɪ ɪleɪɾə, ən u hæd læs naɪt sʌfɝd nɪɹ dɛθ ət ðə hænz ə ðə sintʃæn? ðə slɪm wʊmən lʊkt ʌnkɛɹɪktɝɪstɪkli dɪʃɛvəld. hɝ hɛɹ wɑz pʊl bæk ɪn ə sɝvəsəbəl bʌn, ən əɹ peɪl dʒɹɛs wɑz ɹɪŋkəld.

Next to her was Suana Dragand, First Weaver of the Yellow Ajah. She was a beefy thing with a thrusting chin that matched her unyielding demeanor. Adelorna, the one to make the accusation against Jesse, was beside her. Who could blame the Captain-General for her spitefulness? She who had been birched by Elaida, and who had last night suffered near death at the hands of the Seanchan? The slim woman looked uncharacteristically disheveled. Her hair was pulled back in a serviceable bun, and her pale dress was wrinkled.

ðə læst wʊmən ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz sɹæntʃə kɑlvaɪn, hɛd klɝk ə ðə ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ. ʃi hæd laɪt bɹaʊn hɛɹ ən ə pɪntʃt feɪs; ʃi lʊk pɝpɛtʃuəli əz ɪf ʃid teɪstəd sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi saʊɝ. ðə tʃɹeɪt simd mɔɹ mænəfɛs tədeɪ ðən juʒəwəl.

The last woman in the room was Serancha Colvine, Head Clerk of the Gray Ajah. She had light brown hair and a pinched face; she looked perpetually as if she'd tasted something very sour. The trait seemed more manifest today than usual.

"ʃi hæz ə pɔɪnt, dʒɛsi," fɛɹən sɛd, hɝ lɑdʒɪkəl toʊn ə kɑntʃɹæst wɪð əɹ ɑbviəs pik. "ju wɝ ðə wʌn tə sədʒɛs ðɪs kɔɹs ʌv ækʃən."

"She has a point, Jesse," Ferane said, her logical tone a contrast with her obvious pique. "You were the one to suggest this course of action."

" 'sədʒɛst' ɪz ə stʃɹɔŋ wɝd." dʒɛsi tʊk ə sɪp ə hɝ dʒɹɪŋk. "aɪ sɪmpli mɛnʃən ðəɾ ɪn səm ə ðə . . . mɔɹ pɹaɪvət taʊɝ ɹɛkɝdz, ðəɹ ɑɹ əkaʊns ə taɪmz wən ði ədʒɑ hɛdz ɹuld ɪnstɛɾ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn." ðə θɝtinθ dɪpɑzətɔɹi wɑz noʊn tə ði ədʒɑ hɛdz, ðoʊ ðeɪ kəd nɑt vɪzəɾ ɪɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ ɔlsoʊ sɪɾɝz. ðət dɪdn stɑp moʊst ə ðɛm fɹəm sɛndɪŋ sɪɾɝz tə ɡæðɝ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fɹəm ɪt fəɹ ðɛm. "aɪ meɪ hæv bɪn ðə mɛsənʒɝ, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz ɔfən ðə ɹoʊl ə ðə bɹaʊn. jə ɔl wɝ nɑt soʊ hɛzɪɾənt əz tə bi fɔɹst ɪndə ðɪs kɔɹs ʌv ækʃən."

" 'Suggest' is a strong word." Jesse took a sip of her drink. "I simply mentioned that in some of the . . . more private Tower records, there are accounts of times when the Ajah heads ruled instead of the Amyrlin." The Thirteenth Depository was known to the Ajah heads, though they could not visit it unless they were also Sitters. That didn't stop most of them from sending Sitters to gather information from it for them. "I may have been the messenger, but that is often the role of the Brown. You all were not so hesitant as to be forced into this course of action."

ðəɹ wɝ ə fju saɪdweɪz ɡlænsɪz ət ðæt, ən ðə wɪmən faʊn ɑpɝtunəɾi tə stʌɾi ðɛɹ ti.

There were a few sideways glances at that, and the women found opportunity to study their tea.

jɛs, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɪmplɪkeɪɾɪd, ən ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪt. dʒɛsi wəd nɑt teɪk ðə bleɪm fəɹ ðɪs dɪzæstɝ.

Yes, they were all implicated, and they understood it. Jesse would not take the blame for this disaster.

"ðɛɹ ɪz lɪɾəl jus ɪn əsaɪnɪŋ bleɪm." swænə ətɛmptəd tə bi suðɪŋ, ðoʊ hɝ vɔɪs wɑz leɪst wɪð bɪɾɝnəs.

"There is little use in assigning blame." Suana attempted to be soothing, though her voice was laced with bitterness.

"aɪ woʊn bi dɪflɛktɪd soʊ izəli," ædlɔɹnə ɡɹaʊld. səm ɹiæktəd tə ðə lɔs ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ wɪð sædnəs, ʌðɝz wɪð æŋɡɝ. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl daʊt wɪtʃ wɑz ædlɔɹnəz weɪ. "ə ɡɹeɪv, ɡɹeɪv ɛɹɝ əz bɪn meɪd. ðə waɪt taʊɝ bɝnz, ði æmɪɝlɪn əz bɪn kæptʃɝd baɪ ɪnveɪɾɝz, ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn stɪl wɔks ði ɝθ ənfɛɾɝd. ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld wɪl sun noʊ ʌv əɹ dɪsɡɹeɪs!"

"I won't be deflected so easily," Adelorna growled. Some reacted to the loss of a Warder with sadness, others with anger. There was little doubt which was Adelorna's way. "A grave, grave error has been made. The White Tower burns, the Amyrlin has been captured by invaders, and the Dragon Reborn still walks the earth unfettered. The entire world will soon know of our disgrace!"

"ænd wʌt ɡʊd wɪl ɪt də tə bleɪm wʌn ənʌðɝ?" swænə ɹɪplaɪd. "ɑɹ wi soʊ tʃaɪldɪʃ ðət wɪl spɛn ðɪs miɾɪŋ skwɑbəlɪŋ əbaʊt wɪtʃ wʌn ʌv əs wɪl hæŋ, ɪn ə jusləs ətɛmp tə ɪveɪɾ əɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi?"

"And what good will it do to blame one another?" Suana replied. "Are we so childish that we will spend this meeting squabbling about which one of us will hang, in a useless attempt to evade our responsibility?"

dʒɛsi ɡeɪv kwaɪət θæŋks fəɹ ðə stɝɾi jɛloʊz wɝdz. ʌv kɔɹs, swænə hæd bɪn ðə fɝst ə ði ədʒɑ hɛdz tə əɡɹi tə dʒɛsiz plæn. soʊ ʃid bi nɛkst ɪn laɪn fəɹ ðə mɛɾəfɔɹɪkəl hæŋɪŋ.

Jesse gave quiet thanks for the sturdy Yellow's words. Of course, Suana had been the first of the Ajah heads to agree to Jesse's plan. So she'd be next in line for the metaphorical hanging.

"ʃi hæz ə pɔɪnt." sɹæntʃə tʊk ə sɪp ə hɝ ti. "wi mʌs meɪk pis əmʌŋ aʊɝsɛlvz. ðə taʊɝ nidz liɾɝʃɪp, ən wɝ nɑt gɑnə ɡɛɾ ɪt fɹəm ðə hɔl."

"She has a point." Serancha took a sip of her tea. "We must make peace among ourselves. The Tower needs leadership, and we're not going to get it from the Hall."

"ðæts pɑɹtli əɹ fɔlt əz wɛl," fɛɹən ədmɪɾəd, lʊkɪŋ sɪk.

"That's partly our fault as well," Ferane admitted, looking sick.

ɪt wɑz. ɪt hæd sim laɪk ə bɹɪljən plæn. ðə dɪvɪʒən ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ə soʊ mɛni ɪn ɹɪbɛljən ən ðə ɹeɪzɪŋ ʌv ə nu æmɪɝlɪn, hæd nɑt bɪn ðɛɹ fɔlt. bʌɾ ɪt hæd pɹizɛntəd sɛvɹəl ɑpɝtunəɾiz. ðə fɝs hæd bɪn ði iziəs tə teɪk hoʊld ʌv: sɛn sɪɾɝz tə ðə ɹɛbəlz tə stɪɹ əm ən heɪsən ə ɹɛkənsɪlieɪʃən. ðə moʊs juθfəl ə sɪɾɝz hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən, ðɛɹ ɹipleɪsməns ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɪntɛndəd tə sɝv oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt taɪm. ði ədʒɑ hɛdz hæd bɪn sɝɾən ðɪs ɹɪpəl ʌv ə ɹɪbɛljən kəd bi izəli smuðd oʊvɝ.

It was. It had seemed like a brilliant plan. The division of the Tower, the departure of so many in rebellion and the raising of a new Amyrlin, had not been their fault. But it had presented several opportunities. The first had been the easiest to take hold of: send Sitters to the rebels to steer them and hasten a reconciliation. The most youthful of Sitters had been chosen, their replacements in the Tower intended to serve only a short time. The Ajah heads had been certain this ripple of a rebellion could be easily smoothed over.

ðeɪ hædn teɪkən ɪt sɪɹiəsli ɪnʌf. ðət hæd bɪn ðɛɹ fɝs mɪsteɪk. ðə sɛkənd wɑz mɔɹ daɪɹ. ðəɹ wɝ ɪndid taɪmz ɪn ðə pæst wɛɹ ði ədʒɑ hɛdz - nɑt ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ - hæd lɛd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt hæd bɪn dʌn sikɹɪtli, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn vɛɹi səksɛsfəl. waɪ, ðə ɹeɪn ə səmeɪl sɔɹɛnteɪn wʊɾə bɪn ə kəmplit dɪzæstɝ ɪf ði ədʒɑ hɛdz hædn stɛpt ɪn.

They hadn't taken it seriously enough. That had been their first mistake. The second was more dire. There were indeed times in the past where the Ajah heads - not the Amyrlin Seat or the Hall of the Tower - had led the Aes Sedai. It had been done secretly, of course, but it had been very successful. Why, the reign of Cemaile Sorenthaine would have been a complete disaster if the Ajah heads hadn't stepped in.

ðɪs hæd sim laɪk ə sɪməlɝ əkeɪʒən. ðə deɪz ə ðə læs bæɾəlz əpɹoʊtʃ wɝ ə spɛʃəl taɪm, ɹikwaɪɝɪŋ spɛʃəl ətɛnʃən. ətɛnʃən fɹəm wɪmən ə saʊnd, ɹæʃənəl maɪnz ən ɡɹeɪɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns. wɪmən u kəd spik təɡɛðɝ ɪn kɑnfəɾəns ən dɪsaɪɾ ɑn ðə bɛs kɔɹs, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ði ɑɹɡjəməns ðət ðə hɔl ɡɑɾ ɪntu.

This had seemed like a similar occasion. The days of the Last Battle's approach were a special time, requiring special attention. Attention from women of sound, rational minds and great experience. Women who could speak together in confidence and decide on the best course, avoiding the arguments that the Hall got into.

"wɛɹ dɪd wi ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ, dʒju θɪŋk?" sɹæntʃə æskt kwaɪətli.

"Where did we go wrong, do you think?" Serancha asked quietly.

ðə wɪmən fɛl saɪlənt. nʌn ə ðɛm wɑntəd tə ədmɪɾ aʊtʃɹaɪt ðət ðə plæn hæd bækfaɪɝd.

The women fell silent. None of them wanted to admit outright that the plan had backfired.

ædlɔɹnə sɛɾəld bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ, ɑɹmz foʊldəd, smoʊldɝɪŋ bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ flɪŋɪŋ aʊɾ ækjəzeɪʃənz.

Adelorna settled back in her chair, arms folded, smoldering but no longer flinging out accusations.

"ɪt wɑz ɪleɪɾə," fɛɹən sɛd. "ʃi wɑzn ɛvɝ . . . vɛɹi lɑdʒɪkəl."

"It was Elaida," Ferane said. "She wasn't ever . . . very logical."

"ʃi wɑz ə blʌɾi dɪzæstɝ ɪz wʌt ʃi wɑz," ædlɔɹnə mʌɾɝd.

"She was a bloody disaster is what she was," Adelorna muttered.

"ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ðæt," dʒɛsi ədmɪɾəd. "dɝɛkli tʃuzɪŋ sɪɾɝz wi kəd kəntʃɹoʊl tə ɹipleɪs ðoʊz sɛn tə ðə ɹɛbəlz wɑz ə ɡʊd dɪsɪʒən, bʌt pɝhæps tu ɑbviəs. ðə wɪmən ʌv əɹ oʊn ədʒəz bɪkeɪm səspɪʃəs; aɪ noʊ ʌv sɛvɹəl kɑmɛns meɪd baɪ wɪmən ə ðə bɹaʊn. wəɹ nɑt soʊ əblɪviəs əz ʌðɝz wəd laɪk tə θɪŋk ʌs."

"It was more than that," Jesse admitted. "Directly choosing Sitters we could control to replace those sent to the rebels was a good decision, but perhaps too obvious. The women of our own Ajahs became suspicious; I know of several comments made by women of the Brown. We are not so oblivious as others would like to think us."

sɹæntʃə nɑɾəd. "ɪt smɛld ə kənspɪɹəsi," ʃi sɛd. "ðæt meɪd ðə wɪmən lɛs tʃɹʌstɪŋ. ən ðən ðəɹ wɝ ðə ɹɛbəlz. fɑɹ mɔɹ dɪfəkəl tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðən pɹəzumd."

Serancha nodded. "It smelled of conspiracy," she said. "That made the women less trusting. And then there were the rebels. Far more difficult to control than presumed."

ðə wɪmən nɑɾəd. ðeɪ, laɪk dʒɛsi, hæɾ əsum ðət wɪð pɹɑpɝ dɝɛkʃən, ðə ɹɛbəlz wəd faɪn ðɛɹ weɪ bæk tə ðə taʊɝ ən æsk fɝɡɪvnəs. ðɪs dɪvɪʒən ʃʊɾə ɛndəd wɪð noʊ mɔɹ dæmədʒ ðən ə fju bɹuzd iɡoʊz.

The women nodded. They, like Jesse, had assumed that with proper direction, the rebels would find their way back to the Tower and ask forgiveness. This division should have ended with no more damage than a few bruised egos.

bʌt ðeɪ hædn kaʊntəɾ ɑn haʊ ɹɪzɪljənt, əɹ ɪfɛktɪv, ðə ɹɛbəlz wəd bi. ə fʊl ɑɹmi, əpɪɹɪŋ ɑn ðə ʃɔɹz ɝaʊn tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə snoʊstɔɹm? lɛd baɪ wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst mɪlətɛɹi maɪnz ə ði eɪdʒ? wɪð ə nu æmɪɝlɪn ən ə fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋli ɪfɛktɪv sidʒ? hu cʊɾə ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt? ən səm ə ðə sɪɾɝz ðeɪ hæd sɛn hæd bɪɡʌn saɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz mɔɹ ðən ðə waɪt taʊɝ!

But they hadn't counted on how resilient, or effective, the rebels would be. A full army, appearing on the shores around Tar Valon in the middle of a snowstorm? Led by one of the greatest military minds of the Age? With a new Amyrlin and a frustratingly effective siege? Who could have expected it? And some of the Sitters they had sent had begun siding with the rebels more than the White Tower!

wi nɛvɝ ʃʊɾə lɛɾ ɪleɪɾə dɪsbæn ðə blu ədʒɑ, dʒɛsi θɔt. ðə bluz maɪɾ əv bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə kʌm bæk, hæɾ ɪt nɑt hæpənd. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz sətʃ ə dɪsɑnɝ ðət ðeɪ dʌɡ ɪn. laɪɾ oʊnli nu haʊ deɪnʒɝəs ðət wɑz; ðə hɪstɝiz wɝ fɪld wɪð əkaʊns ə haʊ dɔɡd ðə bluz kəd bi ət ɡɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹst ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ.

We never should have let Elaida disband the Blue Ajah, Jesse thought. The Blues might have been willing to come back, had it not happened. But it was such a dishonor that they dug in. Light only knew how dangerous that was; the histories were filled with accounts of how dogged the Blues could be at getting their way, particularly when they were forced into a corner.

"aɪ θɪŋk ɪts taɪm tə ədmɪt ðət ðəɹ ɪz noʊ hoʊp tə seɪv əɹ plænz," swænə sɛd. "ɑɹ wi əɡɹid?"

"I think it is time to admit that there is no hope to save our plans," Suana said. "Are we agreed?"

"əɡɹid," ædlɔɹnə sɛd.

"Agreed," Adelorna said.

wʌn baɪ wʌn, ðə sɪstɝz nɑɾəd ðɛɹ hɛdz, ən soʊ dɪd dʒɛsi hɝsɛlf. ivən ɪn ðɪs ɹum, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə ədmɪt fɔlt. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm tə kʌt ðɛɹ lɔsəz ən bɪɡɪn ɹibɪldɪŋ.

One by one, the sisters nodded their heads, and so did Jesse herself. Even in this room, it was difficult to admit fault. But it was time to cut their losses and begin rebuilding.

"ðɪs əz ɪts oʊn pɹɑbləmz," sɹæntʃə sɛd, vɔɪs mɔɹ kɑm naʊ. ði ʌðɝ wɪmən lʊk mɔɹ əʃʊɹɾ əz wɛl. ðeɪ dɪdn tʃɹʌst wʌn ənʌðɝ, ðiz faɪv, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ kloʊsɝ tə duɪŋ soʊ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ ɡɹup wɪð ɛni əθɔɹəɾi ɪn ðə hɔl.

"This has its own problems," Serancha said, voice more calm now. The other women looked more assured as well. They didn't trust one another, these five, but they were far closer to doing so than any other group with any authority in the Hall.

"kɛɹ mʌs bi teɪkən," fɛɹən æɾəd. "ðə dɪvɪʒən mʌs bi mɛndɪd."

"Care must be taken," Ferane added. "The division must be mended."

"ðə ɹɪbɛljən wɑz əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə," ædlɔɹnə sɛd. "ɪf ʃiz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ æmɪɝlɪn, ðən wʌɾ ɪz ðəɹ tə ɹəbɛl əɡɛnst?"

"The rebellion was against Elaida," Adelorna said. "If she is no longer Amyrlin, then what is there to rebel against?"

"soʊ wi əbændən hɝ?" dʒɛsi æskt.

"So we abandon her?" Jesse asked.

"ʃi dɪzɝvz ɪt," ædlɔɹnə sɛd. "ʃi sɛd taɪm ən taɪm əɡɛn ðət sintʃæn wɝ noʊ θɹɛt.

"She deserves it," Adelorna said. "She said time and time again that Seanchan were no threat.

wɛl, naʊ ʃiz peɪɪŋ fəɹ əɹ fulɪʃnəs fɝsthænd."

Well, now she is paying for her foolishness firsthand."

"ɪleɪɾə ɪz bɪɑn ɹɛskju," fɛɹən æɾəd. "ðə hɔl əz ɔlɹɛɾi dɪskʌs ðɪs. ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz bɛɹid sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ə mæs ə sintʃæn kæptɪvz, ən wɪv niðɝ ðə ɹisɔɹsɪz nɔɹ ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fəɹ ə ɹɛskju."

"Elaida is beyond rescue," Ferane added. "The Hall has already discussed this. The Amyrlin is buried somewhere in a mass of Seanchan captives, and we have neither the resources nor the information for a rescue."

nɑt tə mɛnʃən əɹ toʊɾəl læk ə dɪzaɪɝ, dʒɛsi æɾəd tə hɝsɛlf. mɛni ʌv ðə sɪɾɝz u hæd bɹɔt ðoʊz pɔɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl wɝ wʌnz u hæd bɪn sɛn tə pɛnəns baɪ ɪleɪɾə. dʒɛsi wɑznt wʌn ə ðoʊz, bʌt ʃi dɪɾ əɡɹi ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə hæɾ ɝn əɹ ɹɪwɔɹd, ɪf oʊnli fəɹ ðə weɪ ʃi hæd dʒɹɪvən ði ədʒəz tə wʌn ənʌðɝz θɹoʊts.

Not to mention our total lack of desire, Jesse added to herself. Many of the Sitters who had brought those points before the Hall were ones who had been sent to penance by Elaida. Jesse wasn't one of those, but she did agree that Elaida had earned her reward, if only for the way she had driven the Ajahs to one another's throats.

"ðɛn wi niɾ ə ɹɪpleɪsmənt," sɹæntʃə sɛd. "bʌt hu?"

"Then we need a replacement," Serancha said. "But who?"

"ɪɾ əz tə bi sʌmwʌn stʃɹɔŋ," swænə sɛd. "bʌt sʌmwʌn kɔʃəs, ənlaɪk ɪleɪɾə. sʌmwʌn hum ðə sɪstɝz kən ɹæli ɝaʊnd."

"It has to be someone strong," Suana said. "But someone cautious, unlike Elaida. Someone whom the sisters can rally around."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt sɹɪn æsnoʊbɑɹ?" dʒɛsi æskt. "ʃi hæz ʃoʊn ənkæni wɪzdəm ə leɪt, ən ʃiz wɛl laɪkt."

"What about Saerin Asnobar?" Jesse asked. "She has shown uncanny wisdom of late, and she is well liked."

"ʌv kɔɹs jud tʃuz ə bɹaʊn," ædlɔɹnə sɛd.

"Of course you'd choose a Brown," Adelorna said.

"ænd waɪ nɑt?" dʒɛsi sɛd, teɪkən əbæk. "ju ɔl hɝd, aɪ θɪŋk, haʊ wɛl ʃi dɪɾ əsumɪŋ kəmæn dʊɹɪŋ ði ətæk læs naɪt?"

"And why not?" Jesse said, taken aback. "You all heard, I think, how well she did assuming command during the attack last night?"

"sin hɹɪmɑn lɛɾ əɹ oʊn pɑkəɾ ə ɹɪzɪstəns," fɛɹən sɛd. "aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk ðɪs wəd bi ə taɪm fəɹ ə wʊmən tə liɾ u ɪz ʌv ən ʌnɪmoʊʃənəl tɛmpɹəmənt. sʌmwʌn u kən pɹəvaɪd ɹæʃənəl ɡaɪɾəns."

"Seaine Herimon led her own pocket of resistance," Ferane said. "I should think this would be a time for a woman to lead who is of an unemotional temperament. Someone who can provide rational guidance."

"nɑnsɛns," swænə sɛd. "waɪts ɑɹ tu ɪmoʊʃənləs; wi doʊnt wɑnə eɪljəneɪt sɪstɝz, wi wɑnə bɹɪŋ əm təɡɛðɝ. hil ðɛm! waɪ, ə jɛloʊ - "

"Nonsense," Suana said. "Whites are too emotionless; we don't want to alienate sisters, we want to bring them together. Heal them! Why, a Yellow - "

"jɔɹ ɔl fɝɡɛɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ," sɹæntʃə ɪntɝdʒɛktɪd. "wʌɾ ɪz niɾəd naʊ? ə ɹɛkənsɪlieɪʃən.

"You're all forgetting something," Serancha interjected. "What is needed now? A reconciliation.

ðə ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ ɪz ðə wʌn ðəɾ əz spɛn sɛntʃɝiz pɹæktəsɪŋ ði ɑɹɾ ə nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən. hu bɛɾɝ tə dil wɪð ə dɪvaɪɾəd taʊɝ, ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf?"

The Gray Ajah is the one that has spent centuries practicing the art of negotiation. Who better to deal with a divided Tower, and the Dragon Reborn himself?"

ædlɔɹnə ɡɹɪp ði ɑɹmɹɛsts ə hɝ tʃɛɹ ən stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ bæk. ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ tɛns əz wɛl. əz ædlɔɹnə oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə spik, dʒɛsi kʌɾ əɹ ɔf.

Adelorna gripped the armrests of her chair and straightened her back. The others were growing tense as well. As Adelorna opened her mouth to speak, Jesse cut her off.

"ɪnʌf!" ʃi ɪntɝdʒɛktɪd. "ɑɹ wi dʒʌs gɑnə skwɑbəl əz ðə hɔl əz bɪn duɪŋ ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ?

"Enough!" she interjected. "Are we just going to squabble as the Hall has been doing all morning?

itʃ ədʒɑ ɔfɝɪŋ ɪts oʊn mɛmbɝz, ən ði ʌðɝz səmɛɹɪli ɹɪdʒɛktɪŋ ðɛm?"

Each Ajah offering its own members, and the others summarily rejecting them?"

ðə ɹum fɛl saɪlən əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz tʃɹu; ðə hɔl hæd bɪn ɪn sɛʃən fəɹ aʊɝz ən hæɾ oʊnli dʒʌst ɡɔn ɪndə ə ʃɔɹt ɹɪsɛs. noʊ wʌn ədʒɑ wɑz kloʊs tə ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪnʌf səpɔɹt fəɹ wʌn ʌv ɪts kændəɾeɪts.

The room fell silent again. It was true; the Hall had been in session for hours and had only just gone into a short recess. No one Ajah was close to getting enough support for one of its candidates.

ðə sɪɾɝz wəd nɑt stæn fəɹ ɛniwʌn nɑɾ ə ðɛɹ oʊn ədʒɑ; ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ ænəmɑsəɾi bɪtwin ðɛm. laɪt, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə mɛs!

The Sitters would not stand for anyone not of their own Ajah; there was too much animosity between them. Light, but this was a mess!

"aɪdili, ɪt ʃəd bi wʌn ʌv əs faɪv," fɛɹən sɛd. "ðæt meɪks sɛns."

"Ideally, it should be one of us five," Ferane said. "That makes sense."

ðə faɪv lʊkt əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, ən dʒɛsi kəd ɹid ðɛɹ ænsɝz tə ðəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz. ðeɪ wɝ ði ədʒɑ hɛdz, ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wɪmən ɪn ðə wɝld. ɹaɪt naʊ, ðeɪ wɝ bælənst ɪn paʊɝ, ən waɪl ðeɪ tʃɹʌstɪɾ itʃ ʌðɝ mɔɹ ðən moʊst, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ ɛni ʌv əm wəɾ əlaʊ ði ɛləveɪʃən ʌv ənʌðɝ ədʒɑ hɛd tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ɪt wəd ɡɪv ðə wʊmən fɑɹ tu mʌtʃ paʊɝ.

The five looked at each other, and Jesse could read their answers to that in their eyes. They were the Ajah heads, the most powerful women in the world. Right now, they were balanced in power, and while they trusted each other more than most, there was no way any of them would allow the elevation of another Ajah head to the Amyrlin Seat. It would give the woman far too much power.

æftɝ ðə feɪljɝ ə ðɛɹ plæn, tʃɹʌst wɑz wɛɹɪŋ vɛɹi θɪn.

After the failure of their plan, trust was wearing very thin.

"ɪf wi doʊn dɪsaɪd sun," swænə noʊɾəd, "ðə hɔl meɪ teɪk ðə dɪsɪʒən fɹəm ʌs."

"If we don't decide soon," Suana noted, "the Hall may take the decision from us."

"bɑ." ædlɔɹnə weɪvd ə hænd. "ðeɪɹ soʊ dɪvaɪɾəd ðeɪ kæn əɡɹi ɑn wʌt kʌlɝ ðə skaɪ ɪz.

"Bah." Adelorna waved a hand. "They're so divided they can't agree on what color the sky is.

ðə sɪɾɝz əv noʊ aɪdiə wʌt ðəɹ duɪŋ."

The Sitters have no idea what they're doing."

"æt list səm ʌv əs dɪdn tʃuz sɪɾɝz u wɝ jɪɹz tu jʌŋ tə bi pleɪst ɪn ðə hɔl,"

"At least some of us didn't choose Sitters who were years too young to be placed in the Hall,"

fɛɹən sɛd.

Ferane said.

"oʊ?" ædlɔɹnə sɛd. "æn jə ɡɑɾ ɝaʊn ðət haʊ, fɛɹən? baɪ tʃuzɪŋ jɝsɛlf əz ə sɪɾɝ?"

"Oh?" Adelorna said. "And you got around that how, Ferane? By choosing yourself as a Sitter?"

fɛɹənz aɪz waɪɾənd wɪð ɹeɪdʒ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə tə ɹaɪl ðət wʊmənz tɛmpɝ.

Ferane's eyes widened with rage. It was not a good idea to rile that woman's temper.

"wi ɔl meɪd mɪsteɪks," dʒɛsi sɛd kwɪkli. "mɛni sɪstɝz wi tʃoʊz wɝ ɑd. wi wɑntəd wɪmən u wəd də ɪɡzækli əz wi sɛd, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd wi ɡɑɾ ə ɡɹup ə skwɑbəlɪŋ bɹæts wɪð ɪnfleɪɾəd əpɪnjənz ə ðɛmsɛlvz, tu ɪmətʃjʊɹ fəɹ mɔɹ tɛmpɹət maɪnz tə ɪnfluəns."

"We all made mistakes," Jesse said quickly. "Many sisters we chose were odd. We wanted women who would do exactly as we said, but instead we got a group of squabbling brats with inflated opinions of themselves, too immature for more temperate minds to influence."

ædlɔɹnə ən fɛɹən meɪɾ ə pɔɪn ə nɑt lʊkɪŋ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ.

Adelorna and Ferane made a point of not looking at each other.

"ðɪs stɪl livz əs wɪð ə pɹɑbləm," swænə sɛd. "wi niɾ ən æmɪɝlɪn. hilɪŋ mʌs bɪɡɪn kwɪkli, wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑst."

"This still leaves us with a problem," Suana said. "We need an Amyrlin. Healing must begin quickly, whatever the cost."

sɹæntʃə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ ɑnəsli kæn θɪŋk ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl wʊmən ðəɾ ə səfɪʃənt nʌmbɝ ə sɪɾɝz wəd səpɔɹt."

Serancha shook her head. "I honestly can't think of a single woman that a sufficient number of Sitters would support."

"aɪ kæn," ædlɔɹnə sɛd sɔfli. "ʃi wɑz mɛnʃən ɪn ðə hɔl sɛvɹəl taɪmz tədeɪ. jə noʊ ʌv hum aɪ spik. ʃiz jʌŋ, ən əɹ sɝkəmstænsəz ɑɹ ənjuʒəwəl, bʌɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz ənjuʒəwəl ət ðə moʊmənt."

"I can," Adelorna said softly. "She was mentioned in the Hall several times today. You know of whom I speak. She is young, and her circumstances are unusual, but everything is unusual at the moment."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," swænə sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "ʃi wɑz mɛnʃənd, jɛs, bʌt baɪ ðoʊz huz moʊɾɪvz aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌst."

"I don't know," Suana said, frowning. "She was mentioned, yes, but by those whose motives I don't trust."

"sɹɪn simz kwaɪt teɪkən wɪð hɝ," dʒɛsi ədmɪɾəd.

"Saerin seems quite taken with her," Jesse admitted.

"ʃiz tu jʌŋ," sɹæntʃə sɛd. "wɝnt wi dʒʌs bɪɹeɪɾɪŋ aʊɝsɛlvz fəɹ tʃuzɪŋ sɪɾɝz u læk ðə nɛsəsɛɹi ɪkspɪɹiəns?"

"She's too young," Serancha said. "Weren't we just berating ourselves for choosing Sitters who lacked the necessary experience?"

"ʃi ɪz jʌŋ, jɛs," fɛɹən noʊɾəd, "bʌt juv tə ədmɪt, ðɛɹz ə sɝɾən . . . flɛɹ tə hɝ. aɪ hɑɹdli θɪŋk ðəɾ ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə taʊɝ stʊɾ ʌp tə ɪleɪɾə əz ɪfɛktɪvli əz ʃi. ən waɪl ɪn sətʃ ə pəzɪʃən əz ʃi wɑz, noʊ lɛs!"

"She is young, yes," Ferane noted, "but you have to admit, there's a certain . . . flair to her. I hardly think that anyone in the Tower stood up to Elaida as effectively as she. And while in such a position as she was, no less!"

"juv hɝd ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ə hɝ ækʃənz dʊɹɪŋ ði ətæk," ædlɔɹnə sɛd. "aɪ kən kənfɝm ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹu. aɪ wɑz ðəɹ wɪð əɹ fəɹ moʊst ʌv ɪt."

"You've heard the reports of her actions during the attack," Adelorna said. "I can confirm that they are true. I was there with her for most of it."

dʒɛsi stɑɹɾəd ət ðɪs. ʃi hædn ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ædlɔɹnə hæd bɪn ɑn ðə twɛnti-sɛkən lɛvəl dʊɹɪŋ ðə faɪɾɪŋ. "ʃʊɹli səm ʌv wʌt wɑz sɛɾ ɪz ɪɡzædʒɝeɪʃən."

Jesse started at this. She hadn't realized that Adelorna had been on the twenty-second level during the fighting. "Surely some of what was said is exaggeration."

ædlɔɹnə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɡɹɪmli. "noʊ. ɪɾ ɪzənt. ɪt saʊnz ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl . . . bʌɾ ɪt . . . wɛl, ɪt hæpənd. ɔl ʌv ɪt."

Adelorna shook her head grimly. "No. It isn't. It sounds incredible . . . but it . . . well, it happened. All of it."

"ðə nɑvəsɪz ɔl bʌt wɝʃəp hɝ," fɛɹən sɛd. "ɪf ðə sɪɾɝz wɪl nɑt stæn fəɹ sʌmwʌn ʌv ənʌðɝ ədʒɑ, wʌɾ ʌv ə wʊmən u nɛvɝ pɪkt ən ədʒɑ? ə wʊmən u hæz səm ɪkspɪɹiəns -  haʊɛvɝ əndʒʌstəfaɪd - ɪn hoʊldɪŋ ðə vɛɹi pəzɪʃən wəɹ dɪskʌsɪŋ?"

"The novices all but worship her," Ferane said. "If the Sitters will not stand for someone of another Ajah, what of a woman who never picked an Ajah? A woman who has some experience -  however unjustified - in holding the very position we are discussing?"

dʒɛsi faʊn hɝsɛlf nɑɾɪŋ. bʌt haʊ hæd ðə jʌŋ ɹɛbəl ɡeɪn sətʃ ɹɪspɛk fɹəm fɛɹən ən ædlɔɹnə?

Jesse found herself nodding. But how had the young rebel gained such respect from Ferane and Adelorna?

"aɪ æm ənsɝɾən," swænə sɛd. "ɪt simz laɪk ənʌðɝ ɹæʃ dɪsɪʒən."

"I am uncertain," Suana said. "It seems like another rash decision."

"dɪdn jə jɝsɛlf seɪ ðət wi hæd tə hil ðə taʊɝ, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə kɑst?" ædlɔɹnə æskt. "kæn jə ɑnəsli θɪŋk ʌv ə bɛɾɝ weɪ tə bɹɪŋ ðə ɹɛbəlz bæk tə ʌs?" ʃi tɝn tə sɹæntʃə. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə bɛs mɛθəɾ ʌv əpizɪŋ ən əfɛndəd pɑɹɾi? wəɾ ɪt nɑt bi tə ɡɪv səm ɡɹaʊn tə ðɛm, æknɑlɪdʒ wʌt ðeɪv dʌn ɹaɪt?"

"Didn't you yourself say that we had to heal the Tower, no matter what the cost?" Adelorna asked. "Can you honestly think of a better way to bring the rebels back to us?" She turned to Serancha. "What is the best method of appeasing an offended party? Would it not be to give some ground to them, acknowledge what they have done right?"

"ʃi hæz ə pɔɪnt," swænə ədmɪɾəd. ʃi ɡɹɪməst, ðən daʊn ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ ti ɪn wʌn ɡʌlp.

"She has a point," Suana admitted. She grimaced, then downed the rest of her tea in one gulp.

"laɪt, bʌt ʃiz ɹaɪt, sɹæntʃə. wɪv tə də ɪt."

"Light, but she's right, Serancha. We have to do it."

ðə ɡɹeɪ lʊkt əɾ itʃ ə ðɛm ɪn tɝn. "ju ɑɹən fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə əsum ðɪs wʊmən wɪl bi lɛd baɪ ðə noʊz, ɑɹ ju? aɪ woʊn stæn fəɹ ðɪs ɪf wɝ sɪmpli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɹieɪɾ ənʌðɝ pʌpət. ðət plæn feɪld. ɪt feɪl mɪzɝəbli."

The Gray looked at each of them in turn. "You aren't foolish enough to assume this woman will be led by the nose, are you? I won't stand for this if we're simply trying to create another puppet. That plan failed. It failed miserably."

"aɪ daʊt wɪl faɪn aʊɝsɛlvz ɪn ðət sɪtʃueɪʃən əɡɛn," fɛɹən sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ feɪnli. "ðɪs wʌn . . . ɪz nɑt ðə taɪp tə bi bʊlid. dʒʌs lʊk ət haʊ ʃi dɛlt wɪð ɪleɪɾəz ɹistʃɹɪkʃənz."

"I doubt we'll find ourselves in that situation again," Ferane said, smiling faintly. "This one . . . is not the type to be bullied. Just look at how she dealt with Elaida's restrictions."

"jɛs," dʒɛsi faʊn hɝsɛlf seɪɪŋ, tə hɝ oʊn sɝpɹaɪz. "sɪstɝz, ɪf wi əɡɹi tə ðɪs, ɪɾəl ɛn əɹ dʒɹim ə ɹulɪŋ fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz. fəɹ bɛɾɝ əɹ wɝs, wɪl bi sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ən æmɪɝlɪn ə stʃɹɛŋkθ."

"Yes," Jesse found herself saying, to her own surprise. "Sisters, if we agree to this, it will end our dream of ruling from the shadows. For better or worse, we'll be setting up an Amyrlin of strength."

"aɪ, fəɹ wʌn," ædlɔɹnə sɛd, "θɪŋk ðæts ə splɛndəɾ aɪdiə. ɪts bɪn tu lɔŋ."

"I, for one," Adelorna said, "think that's a splendid idea. It's been too long."

wʌn baɪ wʌn, ði ʌðɝz əɡɹid.

One by one, the others agreed.

sɪuən stʊd, ənmoʊvɪŋ, bɪniθ ðə baʊz ʌv ə smɔl oʊk. ðə tʃɹi hæd bɪn ɪnɡʌlf baɪ ðə kæmp, ən ɪts ʃeɪd hæd bɪkʌm ə feɪvɝd loʊkeɪʃən fəɹ æksɛptɪɾ ən nɑvəsɪz teɪkɪŋ lʌntʃɪz. ðəɹ wɝ nʌn duɪŋ soʊ ət ðə moʊmənt; ðə sɪstɝz, ʃoʊɪŋ ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ɡʊd dʒʌdʒmən ðɪs taɪm, hæd sɛɾ əm tæsks tə kip əm fɹəm kɑŋɡɹəɡeɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə tɛnt wɛɹ ðə hɔl wɑz miɾɪŋ.

Siuan stood, unmoving, beneath the boughs of a small oak. The tree had been engulfed by the camp, and its shade had become a favored location for Accepted and novices taking lunches. There were none doing so at the moment; the sisters, showing remarkably good judgment this time, had set them tasks to keep them from congregating around the tent where the Hall was meeting.

ən soʊ sɪuən stʊɾ əloʊn, wɑtʃɪŋ əz ʃɛɹiəm pʊl ðə flæps tə ðə lɑɹdʒ pəvɪljən kloʊzd. ʃi wɑz eɪbəl tə ətɛnd naʊ ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz bæk. ɪt wɑz izi tə sɛns wən ðə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ wɑz woʊvən, silɪŋ ðə miɾɪŋ tə ðə fleɪm ən ɪkskluɾɪŋ pɹaɪɪŋ ɪɹz.

And so Siuan stood alone, watching as Sheriam pulled the flaps to the large pavilion closed. She was able to attend now that Egwene was back. It was easy to sense when the ward against eavesdropping was woven, Sealing the meeting to the Flame and excluding prying ears.

ə hæn fɛl ɑn sɪuənz ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi dɪdn dʒʌmp; ʃid sɛns bɹaɪn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ. ðə dʒɛnɝəl wɔkt wɪð stɛlθ, ɔlðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid. hi wɑz gɑnə meɪk ən ɛksələnt wɔɹɾɝ.

A hand fell on Siuan's shoulder. She didn't jump; she'd sensed Bryne approaching. The general walked with stealth, although there was no need. He was going to make an excellent Warder.

hi stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɝ, hæn stɪl kʌmfɝɾəbli ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ən ʃi əlaʊd hɝsɛlf ðə lʌɡʒɝi ʌv teɪkɪŋ dʒʌst ə smɔl stɛp kloʊsɝ tə hɪm. hɪz haɪɾ ən stɝɾinəs fɛlt ɡʊd bɪsaɪd hɝ. laɪk noʊɪŋ ðət ðoʊ ðə skaɪ stɔɹmd ən ðə si ɹeɪdʒd, jəɹ hʌl wɑz kɔlkt ən jəɹ seɪl kɹæftɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs klɔθ.

He stepped up beside her, hand still comfortably on her shoulder, and she allowed herself the luxury of taking just a small step closer to him. His height and sturdiness felt good beside her. Like knowing that though the sky stormed and the sea raged, your hull was caulked and your sail crafted of the strongest cloth.

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ʃɪl tɛl ðɛm?" bɹaɪn æskt, hɪz vɔɪs səbdud.

"What do you think she will tell them?" Bryne asked, his voice subdued.

"aɪ ɑnəsli hæv noʊ aɪdiə. ʃi kəd kɔl fəɹ maɪ stɪlɪŋ, aɪ səpoʊz."

"I honestly have no idea. She could call for my stilling, I suppose."

"aɪ daʊt ðət ʃi wɪl," bɹaɪn æskt. "ʃi ɪz nɑt ðə vɛnʒfəl taɪp. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi noʊz ðət jə dɪd wʌt jə fɛl jə hæd tə. fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɡʊd."

"I doubt that she will," Bryne asked. "She is not the vengeful type. Besides, she knows that you did what you felt you had to. For her own good."

sɪuən ɡɹɪməst. "noʊbɑdi laɪks biɪŋ dɪsoʊbeɪd, list ʌv ɔl ði æmɪɝlɪn. əl peɪ fəɹ læs naɪt, bɹaɪn. jəɹ ɹaɪt ðəɾ ɪt pɹɑbli woʊn bi ɪn ə pʌblɪk weɪ, bʌɾ aɪ wɝi ðəɾ aɪv lɔs ðə ɡɝlz tʃɹʌst."

Siuan grimaced. "Nobody likes being disobeyed, least of all the Amyrlin. I will pay for last night, Bryne. You're right that it probably won't be in a public way, but I worry that I've lost the girl's trust."

"ænd wɑz ɪt wɝθ ðə kɑst?"

"And was it worth the cost?"

"jɛs," sɪuən sɛd. "ʃi dɪdn ɹilaɪz haʊ kloʊz ðɪs bænd wɑz tə slɪpɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. ən wi kʊdnt noʊ ðət ʃid bi seɪf wɪðɪn ðə taʊɝ dʊɹɪŋ ði ətæk. ɪf ðɛɹz wʌn θɪŋ maɪ taɪm ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ tɔt mi, ɪts ðət ðəɹ ɪz ə taɪm fəɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ ən plænɪŋ, bʌt wʌn ɔlsoʊ hæz tə ækt.

"Yes," Siuan said. "She didn't realize how close this band was to slipping away from her. And we couldn't know that she'd be safe within the Tower during the attack. If there's one thing my time in the White Tower taught me, it's that there is a time for gathering and planning, but one also has to act.

jə kæn ɔlweɪz weɪt fəɹ sɝɾənti."

You can't always wait for certainty."

ʃi kəd fil bɹaɪnz smaɪl θɹu ðə bɑnd. laɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə hæv ə wɔɹɾɝ əɡɛn. ʃi hædn ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ ʃid mɪs ðət kʌmfɝɾɪŋ nɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ maɪnd. ðət stəbɪlɪɾi. mɛn θɔt dɪfɹənli fɹəm wɪmən, ən θɪŋz ʃi faʊn kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ən bæfəlɪŋ, bɹaɪn sɔ əz stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝɾ ən sɪmpəl. meɪk jəɹ dɪsɪʒən ən ɡoʊ. ðəɹ wɑz ə hɛlpfəl klɛɹəɾi tə hɪz weɪ ʌv ɹizənɪŋ. nɑt ðəɾ i wɑz sɪmpəl - dʒʌs lɛs ɪnklaɪn tə ɹəɡɹɛt dɪsɪʒənz hiɾ ɔlɹɛɾi meɪd.

She could feel Bryne's smile through the bond. Light, but it was good to have a Warder again. She hadn't realized how much she'd missed that comforting knot of emotions in the back of her mind. That stability. Men thought differently from women, and things she found complicated and baffling, Bryne saw as straightforward and simple. Make your decision and go. There was a helpful clarity to his way of reasoning. Not that he was simple - just less inclined to regret decisions he'd already made.

"ænd wʌɾ ə ði ʌðɝ kɑsts?" bɹaɪn æɾəd.

"And what of the other costs?" Bryne added.

ʃi kəd fil ɪz hɛzəteɪʃən, hɪz wɝi. ʃi tɝn tə hɪm, smaɪlɪŋ ɪn əmjuzmənt. "jɔɹ ə ful, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn."

She could feel his hesitation, his worry. She turned to him, smiling in amusement. "You're a fool, Gareth Bryne."

hi fɹaʊnd.

He frowned.

"bɑndɪŋ jə wɑz nɛvɝ ə kɑst," ʃi sɛd. "wʌtɛvɝ ɛls hæpənz kəz ə ðɪs fiæskoʊ, ðəɾ æspɛkt ə ðə naɪts ɪvɛns wɝ pjʊɹ pɹɑfəɾ ɑn maɪ pɑɹt."

"Bonding you was never a cost," she said. "Whatever else happens because of this fiasco, that aspect of the night's events were pure profit on my part."

hi tʃʌkəld. "wɛl, əl əv tə meɪk ɛkstʃɹə sɝɾən ðət maɪ sɛkən dɪmæn ɪz mɔɹ ənɹiznəbəl, ðɛn."

He chuckled. "Well, I'll have to make extra certain that my second demand is more unreasonable, then."

fɪʃ ɡʌts, sɪuən θɔt. ʃiɾ ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɑɾən əbaʊt ðæt. bɝnɪŋ ənlaɪkli ðət bɹaɪn wʊd, ðoʊ. "ænd wɛn, pɹɪsaɪsli, ɑɹ jə gɑnə meɪk ðɪs ənɹiznəbəl dɪmæn ə mi?"

Fish guts, Siuan thought. She'd almost forgotten about that. Burning unlikely that Bryne would, though. "And when, precisely, are you going to make this unreasonable demand of me?"

hi dɪdn ɹɪspɑn ɪmiɾiətli, ɪnstɛd lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət hɝ, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "ju noʊ," hi sɛd, "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ æktʃəli  ʌndɝstæn jə naʊ, sɪuən sɑntʃ. jə ɑɹ ə wʊmən ʌv ɑnɝ. ɪts dʒʌs ðət noʊbɑdi ɛlsəz ɹɪkwaɪɹməns ə jə kən ɛvɝ bi mɔɹ hɑɹʃ əɹ mɔɹ dɪmændɪŋ ðən jəɹ oʊn ɹɪkwaɪɹməns ə jɝsɛlf. jə oʊ sətʃ ə sɛlf-ɪmpoʊz dɛt tə jəɹ oʊn sɛns ə duɾi ðəɾ aɪ daʊɾ ɛni mɔɹɾəl biɪŋ kəd peɪ ɪt bæk."

He didn't respond immediately, instead looking down at her, rubbing his chin. "You know," he said, "I think I actually understand you now, Siuan Sanche. You are a woman of honor. It's just that nobody else's requirements of you can ever be more harsh or more demanding than your own requirements of yourself. You owe such a self-imposed debt to your own sense of duty that I doubt any mortal being could pay it back."

"ju meɪk mi saʊn sɛntɝɾ ɑn maɪsɛlf," ʃi sɛd.

"You make me sound centered on myself," she said.

"æt list aɪm nɑt kəmpɛɹɪŋ jə tə ə bɔɹ əɡɛn."

"At least I'm not comparing you to a boar again."

"soʊ jə də θɪŋk aɪm sɛlf-sɛntɝd!" ʃi sɛd. bɝn hɪm! hi kəd pɹɑbli sɛns ðət ʃi wɑz æktʃəli  bɑðɝd baɪ hɪz steɪtmənt, ɹæðɝ ðən meɪkɪŋ ɑɹɡjəmən fəɹ ðə seɪk ʌv ɪt. bɝn ɪm əɡɛn!

"So you do think I'm self-centered!" she said. Burn him! He could probably sense that she was actually bothered by his statement, rather than making argument for the sake of it. Burn him again!

"jɔɹ ə dʒɹɪvən wʊmən, sɪuən sɑntʃ," hi sɛd. "dʒɹɪvən tə seɪv ðə wɝl fɹəm ɪtsɛlf. ðæts haʊ jə kən ʃɹʌɡ ɔf ən oʊθ əɹ ən ɔɹɾɝ soʊ izəli."

"You're a driven woman, Siuan Sanche," he said. "Driven to save the world from itself. That's how you can shrug off an oath or an order so easily."

sɪuən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɡɹu vɛɹi tiɾiəs vɛɹi kwɪkli, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. ɑɹ jə gɑnə tɛl mi ðəɾ ʌðɝ dɪmænd, əɹ ɑɹ jə gɑnə meɪk mi weɪt?"

Siuan took a deep breath. "This conversation grew very tedious very quickly, Gareth Bryne. Are you going to tell me that other demand, or are you going to make me wait?"

hi stʌɾid əɹ stoʊn feɪs θɔtfəli. "wɛl, fɹæŋkli, aɪm plænɪŋ tə dɪmæn ðət jə mɛɹi mi."

He studied her stone face thoughtfully. "Well, frankly, I'm planning to demand that you marry me."

ʃi blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. laɪt! ðə bɑn sɛd ðəɾ i wɑz ɑnəst.

She blinked in surprise. Light! The bond said that he was honest.

"bʌɾ oʊnli æftɝ jə fil ðə wɝl kən kɛɹ fəɹ ɪtsɛlf. aɪ woʊn əɡɹi tə ɪt bɪfɔɹ ðɛn, sɪuən.

"But only after you feel the world can care for itself. I won't agree to it before then, Siuan.

juv ɡɪvən jəɹ laɪf tə sʌmθɪŋ. əl si ðət jə sɝvaɪv θɹu ɪt; aɪ hoʊp ðət wʌns jəɹ dʌn, jəl bi wɪlɪŋ tə ɡɪv jəɹ laɪf tə sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɪnstɛd."

You've given your life to something. I'll see that you survive through it; I hope that once you're done, you'll be willing to give your life to something else instead."

ʃi ɹeɪn ɪn əɹ ʃɑk. ʃi wʊdn lɛɾ ə ful mæn meɪk əɹ spitʃləs. "wɛl," ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə seɪ. "aɪ si juv səm sɛns æftɝ ɔl. wi ʃæl si ɪf aɪ əɡɹi tə ðɪs 'dɪmænd' ʌv jʊɹz əɹ nɑt. əl θɪŋk ɑn ɪt."

She reined in her shock. She wouldn't let a fool man make her speechless. "Well," she forced herself to say. "I see you have some sense after all. We shall see if I agree to this 'demand' of yours or not. I will think on it."

bɹaɪn tʃʌkəld əz ʃi tɝn ɝaʊn tə ɹəɡɑɹd ðə pəvɪljən, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛɡwinz ɹiəpɪɹəns.

Bryne chuckled as she turned around to regard the pavilion, waiting for Egwene's reappearance.

hi kəd sɛns ðə tʃɹuθ fɹəm ɪnsaɪd hɝ, dʒʌst əz ʃi kəd sɛns ɪt fɹəm hɪm. laɪt! naʊ ʃi nu waɪ ɡɹinz mɛɹid ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz soʊ ɔfən. filɪŋ ɪz əfɛkʃən fəɹ əɹ waɪl ʃi fɛl ðə seɪm fəɹ ɪm meɪɾ əɹ ɡɪɾi.

He could sense the truth from inside her, just as she could sense it from him. Light! Now she knew why Greens married their Warders so often. Feeling his affection for her while she felt the same for him made her giddy.

hi wɑz ə ful ʌv ə mæn. ən ʃi noʊ lɛs ə ful ʌv ə wʊmən. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɹufəli, bʌt ʃi dɪd lɛt hɝsɛlf lin bæk əɡɛnst ɪm sɔfli əz ðeɪ weɪɾəd, ən i ɹipleɪst ɪz hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ.

He was a fool of a man. And she no less a fool of a woman. She shook her head ruefully, but she did let herself lean back against him softly as they waited, and he replaced his hand on her shoulder.

sɑft, nɑt fɔɹsfəl. wɪlɪŋ tə weɪt. hi dɪɾ ʌndɝstæn hɝ.

Soft, not forceful. Willing to wait. He did understand her.

ɛɡwin stʊd bɪfɔɹ ə ɡɹup ə smuð feɪsəz ðət wɝ fɑɹ tu ɡʊɾ ət haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ æŋzaɪəɾi. baɪ kʌstəm, ʃi hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd kweɪmɛsə tə wiv ðə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, əz ðə ʃɑɹp-noʊzd ɡɹeɪ wɑz ðə jʌŋɡəst əmʌŋ ðə sɪɾɝz ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ tɛnt. ɪt lʊkt ɔlmoʊst ɛmpti wɪð soʊ fju pleɪsəz teɪkən. ə dʌzən wɪmən, tu fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ - ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn θɹi ʌv itʃ, bʌt ði ədʒəz hæɾ ɔl sɛnt wʌn sɪɾɝ wɪð ði ɛnvɔɪ tə ðə blæk taʊɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹipleɪs dɛlænə wɪð nɹisə kæmbɹəl.

Egwene stood before a group of smooth faces that were far too good at hiding their anxiety. By custom, she had ordered Kwamesa to weave the ward against eavesdropping, as the sharp-nosed Gray was the youngest among the Sitters in the large tent. It looked almost empty with so few places taken. A dozen women, two from each Ajah - there would have been three of each, but the Ajahs had all sent one Sitter with the envoy to the Black Tower. The Grays had already replaced Delana with Naorisa Cambral.

twɛlv sɪɾɝz, əlɔŋ wɪð ɛɡwin ən wʌn ʌðɝ. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt lʊk ət ʃɛɹiəm, hu sæɾ ɪn əɹ pleɪs tə ðə saɪd. ʃɛɹiəm hæd sim tʃɹʌbəld əz ʃi ɛntɝd. dɪd ʃi ɹilaɪz wʌɾ ɛɡwin nu?

Twelve Sitters, along with Egwene and one other. Egwene did not look at Sheriam, who sat in her place to the side. Sheriam had seemed troubled as she entered. Did she realize what Egwene knew?

ʃi kʊdnt. ɪf ʃi hæd, ʃid nɛvɝ əv kʌm tə ðə miɾɪŋ.

She couldn't. If she had, she'd never have come to the meeting.

stɪl, noʊɪŋ ʃi wɑz ðəɹ - ən noʊɪŋ wʌt ʃi wɑz - meɪɾ ɛɡwin nɝvəs. ɪn ðə keɪɑs ə ðə sintʃæn ətæk, sɪuən hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə wɑtʃ ʃɛɹiəm. waɪ dɪd ðə kipɝ wɛɹ ə bændɪdʒ ɑn əɹ lɛf hænd? ɛɡwin dɪdn bɪliv əɹ ɪkskjus ʌv ən æksəɾənt waɪl ɹaɪɾɪŋ, hɝ lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn əɹ ɹeɪnz. waɪ hæd ʃi ɹəfjuz hilɪŋ? blæst sɪuən! ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ ʃɛɹiəm, ʃid kʌm tə kɪdnæp ɛɡwin!

Still, knowing she was there - and knowing what she was - made Egwene nervous. In the chaos of the Seanchan attack, Siuan hadn't been able to watch Sheriam. Why did the Keeper wear a bandage on her left hand? Egwene didn't believe her excuse of an accident while riding, her little finger getting caught in her reins. Why had she refused Healing? Blast Siuan! Instead of watching Sheriam, she'd come to kidnap Egwene!

ðə hɔl ɡɹu stɪl, ðə wɪmən weɪɾɪŋ tə si wʌɾ ɛɡwinz ɹɪspɑns wəd bi tə hɝ "fɹiɾəm." ɹoʊmændə, ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik hɛɹ ʌp ɪn ə bʌn, sæt pɹɪmli ɪn ə jɛloʊ dʒɹɛs. ʃi uz sæɾəsfækʃən, waɪl ləleɪn - ɑn ði ɑpəzət saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum - sʌlkt waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə æk plizd əɾ ɛɡwinz ɹɪtɝn. æftɝ wʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd bɪn θɹu ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ðɪs skwɑbəlɪŋ fɛlt ɹədɪkjələsli pɛɾi.

The Hall grew still, the women waiting to see what Egwene's response would be to her "freedom." Romanda, gray-streaked hair up in a bun, sat primly in a yellow dress. She oozed satisfaction, while Lelaine - on the opposite side of the room - sulked while trying to act pleased at Egwene's return. After what Egwene had been through in the White Tower, this squabbling felt ridiculously petty.

ɛɡwin tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. ɪt fɛl soʊ ɡʊd! noʊ bɪɾɝ fɔkɹut tə skwiz əɹ paʊɝ tə ə tʃɹɪkəl, noʊ nid tə ɹitʃ θɹu ʌðɝ wɪmən tə lɛn əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ. noʊ nid fəɹ ə sɑŋɡɹil. swit ðoʊ ðə fluɾəd wɑnz paʊɝ hæd bɪn, biɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ən ə hɝsɛlf wɑz ivən mɔɹ sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ.

Egwene took a deep breath, then embraced the Source. It felt so good! No bitter forkroot to squeeze her power to a trickle, no need to reach through other women to lend her strength. No need for a sa'angreal. Sweet though the fluted wand's power had been, being strong in and of herself was even more satisfying.

sɛvɹəl ə ðə wɪmən fɹaʊn ət ði ækʃən, ən nɑɾ ə fju ʌv əm ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ðɛmsɛlvz, əz ɪf baɪ ɹiflɛks, lʊkɪŋ əbaʊɾ əz ɪf fəɹ deɪnʒɝ.

Several of the women frowned at the action, and not a few of them embraced the Source themselves, as if by reflex, looking about as if for danger.

"ðɛɹ wɪl bi noʊ nid fəɹ ðæt," ɛɡwin sɛd tə ðə wɪmən. "nɑt jɛt. pliz ɹilis ðə sɔɹs."

"There will be no need for that," Egwene said to the women. "Not yet. Please release the Source."

ðeɪ wɝ hɛzɪɾənt, bʌt - ɑstɛnsəbli - ðeɪ æksɛptɪɾ əɹ əz æmɪɝlɪn. wʌn baɪ wʌn ðɛɹ paʊɝ wɪŋkt əweɪ. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt ɹilis ɪt hɝsɛlf.

They were hesitant, but - ostensibly - they accepted her as Amyrlin. One by one their power winked away. Egwene did not release it herself.

"aɪ æm vɛɹi ɡlæd tə si ðət jə ɹɪtɝn seɪfli, mʌðɝ," ləleɪn sɛd. ʃi skɝɾɪd ðə θɹi oʊðz baɪ æɾɪŋ ðə wɝd "seɪfli."

"I am very glad to see that you returned safely, Mother," Lelaine said. She skirted the Three Oaths by adding the word "safely."

"θæŋk ju," ɛɡwin sɛd kɑmli.

"Thank you," Egwene said calmly.

"ju sɛd ðət ðəɹ wɝ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɹɛvəleɪʃənz tə meɪk," vɛɹɪlɪn æɾəd. "ɪz ðɪs ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ətæk?"

"You said that there were important revelations to make," Varilin added. "Is this regarding the Seanchan attack?"

ɛɡwin ɹitʃt tə ðə paʊtʃ ɑn əɹ skɝɾ ən pʊld ɪts kɑntɛns fɹi. ə smuð waɪt ɹɑd wɪð ðə numɝəl θɹi ɪnskɹaɪbd ɑn ɪɾ ɪn ðə skɹɪpt ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, nɪɹ ðə beɪs. ðəɹ wɝ sɛvɹəl ɡæsps.

Egwene reached to the pouch on her skirt and pulled its contents free. A smooth white rod with the numeral three inscribed on it in the script of the Age of Legends, near the base. There were several gasps.

ɛɡwin woʊv spɪɹəɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɑd, ðən spoʊk ɪn ə klɪɹ vɔɪs. "aɪ vaʊ ðəɾ əl spik noʊ wɝd ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu." ʃi fɛl ði oʊθ fɔl oʊvɝ əɹ laɪk ə fɪzɪkəl θɪŋ, hɝ skɪn ɡɹoʊɪŋ taɪɾɝ, pɹɪklɪŋ. ɪt wɑz izi tə ɪɡnɔɹ; ðə peɪn wɑz nʌθɪŋ kəmpɛɹd wɪð wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn θɹu. "aɪ vaʊ ðəɾ əl meɪk noʊ wɛpən fəɹ wʌn mæn tə kɪl ənʌðɝ. aɪ vaʊ ðəɾ əl nɛvɝ juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən ɪksɛpt əɡɛns dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, əɹ ɪn ðə læst ɪkstʃɹim ə dɪfɛndɪŋ maɪ laɪf əɹ ðəɾ ə maɪ wɔɹɾɝ əɹ ʌv ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ."

Egwene wove Spirit into the Rod, then spoke in a clear voice. "I vow that I will speak no word that is not true." She felt the oath fall over her like a physical thing, her skin growing tighter, prickling. It was easy to ignore; the pain was nothing compared with what she had been through. "I vow that I will make no weapon for one man to kill another. I vow that I will never use the One Power as a weapon except against Darkfriends and Shadowspawn, or in the last extreme of defending my life or that of my Warder or of another sister."

ðə hɔl wɑz saɪlənt. ɛɡwin ɹilist əɹ wiv. hɝ skɪn fɛl soʊ ɑd! əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd pɪntʃt ði ɛksɛs ʌp ət ðə beɪs ə hɝ nɛk ən əlɔŋ əɹ spaɪn, jæŋkɪŋ ɪɾ ən baɪndɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn pleɪs.

The Hall was silent. Egwene released her weave. Her skin felt so odd! As if someone had pinched the excess up at the base of her neck and along her spine, yanking it and binding it in place.

"lɛɾ ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bi θɔt ðəɾ aɪ kən əvɔɪd kipɪŋ ðə θɹi oʊðz," ɛɡwin ənaʊnst. "lɛɾ ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bi bɹiðd ðəɾ aɪm nɑt fʊli ɛɛs sədaɪ." nʌn ə ðɛm sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ nɑt hævɪŋ teɪkən ðə tɛs tə ɡeɪn ðə ʃɔl. ʃi wəd si tə ðəɾ ənʌðɝ deɪ. "ænd naʊ ðət juv sin mi juz ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ən noʊ ðəɾ aɪ kænɑt laɪ, əl tɛl jə sʌmθɪŋ. dʊɹɪŋ maɪ taɪm ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ə sɪstɝ keɪm tə mi ən kənfaɪɾəd ðət ʃi wɑz blæk ədʒɑ."

"Let it no longer be thought that I can avoid keeping the Three Oaths," Egwene announced. "Let it no longer be breathed that I am not fully Aes Sedai." None of them said anything about her not having taken the test to gain the shawl. She would see to that another day. "And now that you've seen me use the Oath Rod and know that I cannot lie, I will tell you something. During my time in the White Tower, a sister came to me and confided that she was Black Ajah."

ðə wɪmənz aɪz bʌlʒd, ən sɛvɹəl ɡæsp kwaɪətli.

The women's eyes bulged, and several gasped quietly.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ noʊ wi doʊn laɪk tə spik ə ðɛm, bʌt kən ɛni ʌv əs ɑnəsli kleɪm ðət ðə blæk ədʒɑ dʌz nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst? kən jə hoʊl tə ði oʊðz waɪl seɪɪŋ ðət juv nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝd ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi - ivən ðə laɪklihʊd - ʌv ðəɹ biɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz əmʌŋ ʌs?"

"Yes," Egwene said. "I know we don't like to speak of them, but can any of us honestly claim that the Black Ajah does not exist? Can you hold to the oaths while saying that you've never considered the possibility - even the likelihood - of there being Darkfriends among us?"

noʊbɑdi dɛɹd tə. ðə tɛn fɛl hɑt dɪspaɪt ði ɝli aʊɝ. stʌfi. nʌn ə ðɛm swɛɾɪd, ʌv kɔɹs  - ðeɪ nu ði eɪdʒ-oʊl tʃɹɪk ʌv əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðæt.

Nobody dared to. The tent felt hot despite the early hour. Stuffy. None of them sweated, of course  - they knew the age-old trick of avoiding that.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ɪɾ ɪz ʃeɪmfəl, bʌɾ ɪts ə tʃɹuθ ðət wi - əz ðə liɾɝz ʌv əɹ pipəl - mʌst ədmɪt. nɑɾ ɪn pʌblɪk; bʌɾ əmʌŋ aʊɝsɛlvz ðəɹ ɪz noʊ əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɪt. aɪ hæv sin fɝsthænd wʌt dɪstʃɹʌst ən kwaɪət pɑlətɪkɪŋ kən də tə ə pipəl. əl nɑt si ðə seɪm dɪziz ɪnfɛkt əs hɪɹ. wəɹ ə dɪfɹən ədʒəz, bʌt wəɹ sɪŋɡəl ɪn pɝpəs. wi nid tə noʊ ðət wi kən tʃɹʌst wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪmplɪsətli, kəz ðəɹ ɪz vɛɹi lɪɾəl ɛls ɪn ðɪs wɝl ðət kən bi tʃɹʌstɪd."

"Yes," Egwene said, "It is shameful, but it is a truth that we - as the leaders of our people - must admit. Not in public; but among ourselves there is no avoiding it. I have seen firsthand what distrust and quiet politicking can do to a people. I will not see the same disease infect us here. We are of different Ajahs, but we are single in purpose. We need to know that we can trust one another implicitly, because there is very little else in this world that can be trusted."

ɛɡwin lʊk daʊn ət ði oʊθ ɹɑd, wɪtʃ ʃid fɛtʃt ɝli ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ fɹəm sɹɪn. ʃi ɹʌbd əɹ θʌm ɑn ɪt. aɪ wɪʃ jud bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪn ðɪs wən jə vɪzəɾəd, vɛɹɪn, ʃi θɔt.

Egwene looked down at the Oath Rod, which she'd fetched early in the morning from Saerin. She rubbed her thumb on it. I wish you'd been able to find this when you visited, Verin, she thought.

pɝhæps ɪt wʊdn əv seɪv ju, bʌɾ aɪ wʊɾə laɪk tə tʃɹaɪ. aɪ kəd juz jəɹ eɪd.

Perhaps it wouldn't have saved you, but I would have liked to try. I could use your aid.

ɛɡwin lʊkt ʌp. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd," ʃi ənaʊns tə ðə ɹum. "æn jə noʊ ɪt kænɑt bi ə laɪ."

Egwene looked up. "I am not a Darkfriend," she announced to the room. "And you know it cannot be a lie."

ðə sɪɾɝz lʊk pɝplɛkst. wɛl, ðeɪ wəd sun si ðə pɔɪnt.

The Sitters looked perplexed. Well, they would soon see the point.

"ɪɾ ɪz taɪm fəɹ əs tə pɹuv aʊɝsɛlvz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "sʌm klɛvɝ wɪmən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ hɪɾ əpɑn ðɪs aɪdiə, ən aɪ ɪntɛn tə ɪkspæn ɪt. wɪl itʃ ɪn tɝn juz ði oʊθ ɹɑd tə ɹilis aʊɝsɛlvz fɹəm ðə θɹi oʊðz, ðən ɹɛswɛɹ əm ɪn tɝn. wʌns wəɹ ɔl baʊnd, wɪl bi eɪbəl tə pɹɑməs ðət wəɹ nɑt sɝvəns ʌv - "

"It is time for us to prove ourselves," Egwene said. "Some clever women in the White Tower hit upon this idea, and I intend to expand it. We will each in turn use the Oath Rod to release ourselves from the Three Oaths, then reswear them in turn. Once we are all bound, we will be able to promise that we are not servants of - "

ʃɛɹiəm ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. ɛɡwin hæd bɪn æntɪsəpeɪɾɪŋ ðæt. ʃi slæmd ə ʃil bɪtwin ʃɛɹiəm ən ðə sɔɹs, kɑzɪŋ ðə wʊmən tə ɡæsp. bɛɹænə kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ʃɑk, ən sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ wɪmən ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, lʊkɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt.

Sheriam embraced the Source. Egwene had been anticipating that. She slammed a shield between Sheriam and the Source, causing the woman to gasp. Berana cried out in shock, and several other women embraced the Source, looking this way and that.

ɛɡwin tɝn ən mɛt ʃɛɹiəmz aɪz. ðə wʊmənz feɪs wɑz nɪɹli əz ɹɛɾ əz əɹ hɛɹ, ən ʃi wɑz bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊt kwɪkli. laɪk ə kæptʃɝd ɹæbət, ɪts lɛɡ ɪn ə snɛɹ, aɪz waɪd wɪð fɹaɪt. ʃi klʌtʃt əɹ bændədʒ hænd.

Egwene turned and met Sheriam's eyes. The woman's face was nearly as red as her hair, and she was breathing in and out quickly. Like a captured rabbit, its leg in a snare, eyes wide with fright. She clutched her bandaged hand.

oʊ, ʃɛɹiəm, ɛɡwin θɔt. aɪ hæd hoʊp ðət vɛɹɪn wɑz ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ju.

Oh, Sheriam, Egwene thought. I had hoped that Verin was wrong about you.

"ɛɡwin?" ʃɛɹiəm æskt ənkʌmftəbli. "aɪ wɑz dʒʌst - "

"Egwene?" Sheriam asked uncomfortably. "I was just - "

ɛɡwin stɛp fɔɹwɝd. "ɑɹ jə blæk ədʒɑ, ʃɛɹiəm?"

Egwene stepped forward. "Are you Black Ajah, Sheriam?"

"wʌt? ʌv kɔɹs nɑt!"

"What? Of course not!"

"du jə kɑnsɔɹt wɪð ðə fɔɹseɪkən?"

"Do you consort with the Forsaken?"

"noʊ!" ʃɛɹiəm sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ tə ðə saɪdz.

"No!" Sheriam said, glancing to the sides.

"du jə sɝv ðə dɑɹk wʌn?"

"Do you serve the Dark One?"

"noʊ!"

"No!"

"hæv jə bɪn ɹilis fɹəm jəɹ oʊðz?"

"Have you been released from your oaths?"

"noʊ!"

"No!"

"du juv ɹɛd hɛɹ?"

"Do you have red hair?"

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt, aɪ nɛvɝ - " ʃi fɹoʊz.

"Of course not, I never - " She froze.

ən θæŋk jə fəɹ ðət tʃɹɪk əz wɛl, vɛɹɪn, ɛɡwin θɔt wɪð ə mɛntəl saɪ.

And thank you for that trick as well, Verin, Egwene thought with a mental sigh.

ðə tɛnt ɡɹu vɛɹi, vɛɹi stɪl.

The tent grew very, very still.

"aɪ mɪsspoʊk, ʌv kɔɹs," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd, swɛɾɪŋ nɝvəsli. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊ wʌt kwɛstʃən aɪ wɑz ænsɝɪŋ. aɪ kæn laɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. nʌn ʌv əs kæn. . . ."

"I misspoke, of course," Sheriam said, sweating nervously. "I didn't know what question I was answering. I can't lie, of course. None of us can. . . ."

ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf əz ɛɡwin hɛld aʊt ði oʊθ ɹɑd. "pɹuv ɪt, ʃɛɹiəm. ðə wʊmən u keɪm tə mi ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɡeɪv mi jəɹ neɪm əz ə liɾɝ əmʌŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ."

She trailed off as Egwene held out the Oath Rod. "Prove it, Sheriam. The woman who came to me in the Tower gave me your name as a leader among the Black Ajah."

ʃɛɹiəm mɛɾ ɛɡwinz aɪz. "ɑ, ðɛn," ðə wʊmən sɛd sɔfli, aɪz mɔɹnfəl. "hu wɑz ɪt, naʊ, hu keɪm tə ju?"

Sheriam met Egwene's eyes. "Ah, then," the woman said softly, eyes mournful. "Who was it, now, who came to you?"

"vɛɹɪn mæθwɪn."

"Verin Mathwin."

"wɛl, wɛl," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɑn əɹ tʃɛɹ. "nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪɾ ə hɝ, əl seɪ. haʊ dɪd ʃi ɡɛt pæs ði oʊðz tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd?"

"Well, well," Sheriam said, settling back on her chair. "Never expected it of her, I'll say. How did she get past the oaths to the Great Lord?"

"ʃi dʒɹæŋk pɔɪzən," ɛɡwin sɛd, hɑɹt twɪstɪŋ.

"She drank poison," Egwene said, heart twisting.

"vɛɹi klɛvɝ." ðə fleɪm-hɛɹd wʊmən nɑɾəd. "aɪ kəd nɛvɝ bɹɪŋ maɪsɛlf tə də sətʃ ə θɪŋ.

"Very clever." The flame-haired woman nodded. "I could never bring myself to do such a thing.

nɛvɝ ɪndid. . . ."

Never indeed. . . ."

ɛɡwin woʊv bɑnz ʌv ɛɹ ən ɹæpt ʃɛɹiəm ɪn ðɛm, ðən taɪɾ ɔf ðə wivz. ʃi tɝn bæk tə ən ɪnkɹɛdʒələs ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən, waɪt-feɪst. səm tɛɹəfaɪd. "ðə wɝl mɑɹtʃɪz tə ðə læs bæɾəl," ɛɡwin sɛd stɝnli. "dɪd jə ɪkspɛk ðəɾ əɹ ɛnəmiz wəd liv əs əloʊn?"

Egwene wove bonds of Air and wrapped Sheriam in them, then tied off the weaves. She turned back to an incredulous group of women, white-faced. Some terrified. "The world marches to the Last Battle," Egwene said sternly. "Did you expect that our enemies would leave us alone?"

"hu ɛls?" ləleɪn wɪspɝd. "hu ɛls wɑz mɛnʃənd?"

"Who else?" Lelaine whispered. "Who else was mentioned?"

"mɛni ʌðɝz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "sɪɾɝz əmʌŋ ðɛm."

"Many others," Egwene said. "Sitters among them."

mɔɹiə lɛp tə hɝ fiɾ ən ɹæn fəɹ ði ɛɡzɪt. ʃi bɛɹli meɪɾ ɪt tu stɛps. ə dʌzən dɪfɹən sɪstɝz ɛnkloʊz ðə fɔɹmɝ blu wɪð ʃilz ən baʊn əɹ ɪn wivz ʌv ɛɹ. ɪn sɛkənz, ʃi wɑz hæŋɪŋ, ɡæɡd, tɪɹz likɪŋ daʊn ðə saɪdz ə hɝ oʊvəl feɪs.

Moria leaped to her feet and ran for the exit. She barely made it two steps. A dozen different sisters enclosed the former Blue with shields and bound her in weaves of Air. In seconds, she was hanging, gagged, tears leaking down the sides of her oval face.

ɹoʊmændə klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ, wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə wʊmən. "boʊθ fɹəm ðə blu," ʃi noʊɾəd. "ðɪs wɑz ə dʒɹəmæɾɪk weɪ tə meɪk ðə ɹɛvəleɪʃənz, ɛɡwin."

Romanda clicked her tongue, walking around the woman. "Both from the Blue," she noted. "This was a dramatic way to make the revelations, Egwene."

"ju wɪl ædʒɹɛs mi əz 'mʌðɝ,' ɹoʊmændə," ɛɡwin sɛd, wɔkɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə deɪz. "æn ɪts nɑt soʊ ɑd ðət ðəɹ wəd bi ə haɪɝ pɝsɛntədʒ ə ðɛm əmʌŋ ðə blu hɪɹ, sɪns ðəɾ ɪntaɪɝ ədʒɑ flɛd ðə waɪt taʊɝ." ʃi hɛld ʌp ði oʊθ ɹɑd. "ðə ɹizən aɪ hæd tə meɪk ðə ɹɛvəleɪʃən ðɪs weɪ wɑz sɪmpəl. haʊ wəd juv ɹɪspɑndɪɾ ɪf aɪd sɪmpli dɪklɛɹɾ əm tə bi blæk wɪθaʊɾ ɔfɝɪŋ pɹuf?"

"You will address me as 'Mother,' Romanda," Egwene said, walking down from the dais.
