"And it is not so odd that there would be a higher percentage of them among the Blue here, since that entire Ajah fled the White Tower." She held up the Oath Rod. "The reason I had to make the revelation this way was simple. How would you have responded if I'd simply declared them to be Black without offering proof?"

ɹoʊmændə nɑɾəd əɹ hɛd. "ju ɑɹ kɝɛkt ɑn boʊθ kaʊns, mʌðɝ," ʃi ədmɪɾəd.

Romanda nodded her head. "You are correct on both counts, Mother," she admitted.

"ðɛn jə wʊdn maɪn biɪŋ ðə fɝs tə ɹiteɪk ði oʊðz, aɪ pɹɪzum?"

"Then you wouldn't mind being the first to retake the oaths, I presume?"

ɹoʊmændə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli bɹifli, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə tu wɪmən baʊn ɪn ɛɹ. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə ɹum hɛl tə ðə sɔɹs, aɪɪŋ ði ʌðɝz əz ɪf ðeɪ maɪt ɡɹoʊ kɑpɝsneɪks fəɹ hɛɹ əɾ ɛni moʊmənt.

Romanda hesitated only briefly, glancing at the two women bound in Air. Almost everyone in the room held to the Source, eyeing the others as if they might grow coppersnakes for hair at any moment.

ɹoʊmændə tʊk ði oʊθ ɹɑd, ən dɪɾ əz ɪnstʃɹʌktəd, ɹilisɪŋ hɝsɛlf fɹəm ði oʊðz. ðə pɹɑsɛs wɑz ɑbviəsli peɪnfəl, bʌt ʃi hɛl hɝsɛlf tə ə kəntʃɹoʊld, hɪsɪŋ ɪnteɪk ə bɹɛθ. ði ʌðɝz wɑtʃt kɛɹfəli fəɹ ə tʃɹɪk, bʌt ɹoʊmændə wɑz stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɹɛswɛɹɪŋ. ʃi hændəd ðə ɹɑd bæk tə ɛɡwin. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd," ʃi sɛd. "æn aɪ nɛvɝ əv bɪn."

Romanda took the Oath Rod, and did as instructed, releasing herself from the oaths. The process was obviously painful, but she held herself to a controlled, hissing intake of breath. The others watched carefully for a trick, but Romanda was straightforward in reswearing. She handed the rod back to Egwene. "I am not a Darkfriend," she said. "And I never have been."

ɛɡwin æksɛptɪd ði oʊθ ɹɑd bæk. "θæŋk ju, ɹoʊmændə," ʃi sɛd. "ləleɪn, dʒju wɪʃ tə bi nɛkst?"

Egwene accepted the Oath Rod back. "Thank you, Romanda," she said. "Lelaine, do you wish to be next?"

"ɡlædli," ðə wʊmən sɛd. ʃi pɹɑbli fɛlt ə nid tə vɪndəkeɪt ðə blu. wʌn baɪ wʌn, ði ʌðɝ wɪmən fɔɹswɔɹ - ɡæspɪŋ əɹ hɪsɪŋ ət ðə peɪn ʌv ɪt - ðən swɔɹ əɡɛn ən pɹɑməs ðət ðeɪ wɝ nɑt dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɛɡwin lɛɾ aʊɾ ə saɪlən saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif əɾ itʃ wʌn. vɛɹɪn hæɾ ədmɪɾəd ðət ðəɹ wəd bi sɪstɝz ʃi dɪdnt ɡɛt, ən ðəɾ ɛɡwin maɪt dɪskʌvɝ ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə ðə blæk əmʌŋ ðə sɪɾɝz.

"Gladly," the woman said. She probably felt a need to vindicate the Blue. One by one, the other women forswore - gasping or hissing at the pain of it - then swore again and promised that they were not Darkfriends. Egwene let out a silent sigh of relief at each one. Verin had admitted that there would be sisters she didn't get, and that Egwene might discover other members of the Black among the Sitters.

wən kweɪmɛsə, ðə læst, hændəd ðə ɹɑd bæk tə ɛɡwin ən dɪklɛɹd hɝsɛlf nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ðəɹ wɑz ə vɪzəbəl ɹilis ə tɛnʃən ɪn ðə ɹum.

When Kwamesa, the last, handed the Rod back to Egwene and declared herself not a Darkfriend, there was a visible release of tension in the room.

"vɛɹi ɡʊd," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə stæn ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɹum. "fɹʌm naʊ ɑn, wi kəntɪnju əz wʌn. noʊ mɔɹ skwɑbəlɪŋ. noʊ mɔɹ faɪɾɪŋ. wi itʃ əv ðə bɛst ɪntʃɹəsts ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ -  ən ðə wɝld ɪtsɛlf - ət hɑɹt. ðə twɛlv ʌv ʌs, ət list, ɑɹ kɑnfəɾənt ɪn wʌn ənʌðɝ.

"Very good," Egwene said, returning to stand at the head of the room. "From now on, we continue as one. No more squabbling. No more fighting. We each have the best interests of the White Tower -  and the world itself - at heart. The twelve of us, at least, are confident in one another.

"ə klɛnzɪŋ ɪz nɛvɝ izi. ɪts ɔfən peɪnfəl. tədeɪ, wɪv klɛnzd aʊɝsɛlvz, bʌt wʌt wɪv tə də nɛkst wɪl bi nɪɹli əz peɪnfəl."

"A cleansing is never easy. It is often painful. Today, we have cleansed ourselves, but what we have to do next will be nearly as painful."

"ju . . . noʊ ðə neɪmz ə mɛni ʌðɝz?" tɑkimə æskt, fəɹ wʌns lʊkɪŋ nɑɾ ə bɪt dɪstʃɹæktəd.

"You . . . know the names of many others?" Takima asked, for once looking not a bit distracted.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd. "oʊvɝ tu hʌnʒɹəd toʊɾəl, səm fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ. səm sɛvənti əmʌŋ əs hɪɹ ɪn ðɪs kæmp. aɪ hæv ðə neɪmz." ʃi hæd ɹɪtɝn ɪn ðə naɪt tə fɛtʃ vɛɹɪnz bʊks fɹəm əɹ ɹum. ðeɪ wɝ naʊ seɪfli hɪɾən ɪn əɹ tɛnt, ɪnvɪzəbəl. "aɪ pɹəpoʊz ðət wi ɝɛs ðɛm, ðoʊ ɪɾəl bi dɪfəkəlt, əz wɪl əv tə siz ɔl ə ðɛm əz saɪməlteɪniəsli əz pɑsəbəl." ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪɾəst ædvæntɪdʒ, bɪɑn sɝpɹaɪz, wɑz gɑnə bi ði ɪnhɪɹənli dɪstʃɹʌstɪŋ neɪtʃɝ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ. vɛɹɪn ən ʌðɝ sɔɹsəz hæɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət fju sɪstɝz ɪn ðə blæk nu mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl ʌv ʌðɝ neɪmz.

"Yes," Egwene said. "Over two hundred total, some from each Ajah. Some seventy among us here in this camp. I have the names." She had returned in the night to fetch Verin's books from her room. They were now safely hidden in her tent, invisible. "I propose that we arrest them, though it will be difficult, as we will have to seize all of them as simultaneously as possible." Their greatest advantage, beyond surprise, was going to be the inherently distrusting nature of the Black Ajah. Verin and other sources had indicated that few sisters in the Black knew more than a handful of other names.

ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪntaɪɝ ɹaɪt-ʌp ɪn ðə bʊk əbaʊt blæk ədʒɑ ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, ən ðɛɹ sɪstəm ʌv ɡɹups noʊn əz "hɑɹts" ðət hæd mɪnəməl ɪntɝækʃən tə kip əm hɪɾən. hoʊpfəli, ðət vɛɹi sɪstəm wəd sloʊ ðɛɹ ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ.

There was an entire write-up in the book about Black Ajah organization, and their system of groups known as "hearts" that had minimal interaction to keep them hidden. Hopefully, that very system would slow their realizing what was happening.

ðə sɪɾɝz lʊk dɔntɪd. Shadowspawn can't move through gateways, so they can't move as quickly as I can. By the time they've engaged Lan, I'll be past them and attacking directly at the Dark One's heart.

"aɪ doʊn plæn tə əbændən ðə sʌðɝn lænz, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl. wən ðə tʃɹɑləks pʌntʃ θɹu ðə ɡæp, ðəl bɹeɪk ʌp ɪndə fɪsts tə ɪnveɪd. ðæts wən maɪ fɔɹsɪz wɪl hɪt ðɛm, lɛd baɪ bæʃɪɹ, tʃɹævlɪŋ baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ tə stʃɹaɪk əɾ itʃ ɡɹup ə tʃɹɑləks fɹəm ðə saɪdz əɹ bɪhaɪnd. ðət weɪ, wi kən pɪk ðə bɛs bæɾəlfildz tə suɾ əɹ nidz."

"I don't plan to abandon the southern lands, not at all. When the Trollocs punch through the Gap, they will break up into fists to invade. That's when my forces will hit them, led by Bashere, Traveling by gateway to strike at each group of Trollocs from the sides or behind. That way, we can pick the best battlefields to suit our needs."

"ɹænd," nɪneɪiv sɛd, hɝ æŋɡɝ feɪɾɪŋ tə hɔɹɝ. "læn wɪl daɪ!"

"Rand," Nynaeve said, her anger fading to horror. "Lan will die!"

"ðɛn u æm aɪ tə dɪnaɪ hɪm ðæt?" ɹænd sɛd. "wi ɔl dɪzɝv ðə tʃæns tə faɪn pis."

"Then who am I to deny him that?" Rand said. "We all deserve the chance to find peace."

nɪneɪiv faʊn əɹ maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən. hi æktʃəli  bɪliv ðæt! əɹ i wɑz kənvɪnsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə bɪliv ɪt, ət list.

Nynaeve found her mouth hanging open. He actually believed that! Or he was convincing himself to believe it, at least.

"maɪ duɾi ɪz tə kɪl ðə dɑɹk wʌn," ɹænd sɛd, əz ɪf tə hɪmsɛlf. "aɪ kɪl hɪm, ðən aɪ daɪ. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl."

"My duty is to kill the Dark One," Rand said, as if to himself. "I kill him, then I die. That is all."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"ðæɾ ɪz ɪnʌf, nɪneɪiv." ɹænd spoʊk sɔfli ɪn ðət deɪnʒɝəs vɔɪs ə hɪz. hi wəd nɑt bi pɹɛs fɝðɝ.

"That is enough, Nynaeve." Rand spoke softly in that dangerous voice of his. He would not be pressed further.

nɪneɪiv sæt bæk, stuɪŋ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd haʊ tə pɹɛs ɪm ɑn ðə tɑpɪk. laɪt! hi wəd liv ðə pipəl ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz tə sʌfɝ ən daɪ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɪnveɪʒənz? ðə pipəl ðəɹ wʊdn kɛɹ ɪf ðə dɑɹk wʌn hæd bɪn dɪfiɾəd - ðeɪ wəd bi kʊkɪŋ ɪn stupəts. ðət wəd liv læn ən ðə mɔlkɪɹi tə faɪɾ əloʊn, ə taɪni fɔɹs tə ɹɪzɪs ðə maɪɾ ʌv ɛvɹi mɑnstɝ ðət ðə blaɪt kəd spɪɾ aʊt.

Nynaeve sat back, stewing, trying to decide how to press him on the topic. Light! He would leave the people of the Borderlands to suffer and die in the Trolloc invasions? The people there wouldn't care if the Dark One had been defeated - they would be cooking in stewpots. That would leave Lan and the Malkieri to fight alone, a tiny force to resist the might of every monster that the Blight could spit out.

ðə sintʃæn wəd weɪdʒ ðɛɹ wɔɹ tə ðə saʊθ ən ðə wɛst. ðə tʃɹɑləks wəɾ ətæk fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ ən ði ist. ðə tu wəd mit, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ændɝ ən ði ʌðɝ kɪŋdəmz wəd bi tɝn ɪndə ə mæsɪv bæɾəlɡɹaʊnd, ðə pipəl ðəɹ - ɡʊd pipəl, laɪk ðoʊz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz -  wəɾ əv noʊ tʃæns əɡɛnst sətʃ wɔɹfɛɹ. ðeɪd bi kɹʌʃt.

The Seanchan would wage their war to the south and the west. The Trollocs would attack from the north and the east. The two would meet, eventually. Andor and the other kingdoms would be turned into a massive battleground, the people there - good people, like those in the Two Rivers -  would have no chance against such warfare. They'd be crushed.

soʊ wʌt kəd ʃi də tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪt? ʃi hæd tə kʌm ʌp wɪð ə nu stʃɹæɾədʒi tə ɪnfluəns ɹænd.

So what could she do to change it? She had to come up with a new strategy to influence Rand.

ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɪn əɹ hɑɹt, pɔɪntəɾ ət pɹətɛktɪŋ læn. ʃi hæd tə ɡɛɾ ɪm hɛlp!

Everything, in her heart, pointed at protecting Lan. She had to get him help!

ðə ɡɹup ɹoʊd θɹu oʊpən ɡɹæslæn spɑɾəd əkeɪʒənəli wɪð fɑɹmz. ðeɪ pæst wʌn ɑn ðə ɹaɪt, ə sɑlətɛɹi fɑɹmstɛd nɑɾ ənlaɪk mɛni bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. jɛt, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ʃid nɛvɝ sin ə fɑɹmɝ wɑtʃ tʃɹævəlɝz wɪð sətʃ oʊpən hɑstɪləɾi. ðə ɹɛd-bɪɹɾəd mæn ɪn dɝɾid tʃɹaʊzɝz, wɪð slivz ɹoʊl nɪɹli tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, lin əɡɛnst ə hæf-fɪnɪʃt fɛns, hɪz æks leɪd kæʒəwəli - bʌt vɛɹi vɪzəbli - ɑn ðə lɔɡz bɪsaɪd hɪm.

The group rode through open grassland spotted occasionally with farms. They passed one on the right, a solitary farmstead not unlike many back in the Two Rivers. Yet, in the Two Rivers, she'd never seen a farmer watch travelers with such open hostility. The red-bearded man in dirtied trousers, with sleeves rolled nearly to his shoulders, leaned against a half-finished fence, his axe laid casually - but very visibly - on the logs beside him.

hɪz fil hæd sin bɛɾɝ jɪɹz; ðoʊ ðə sɔɪl hæd bɪn nitli plaʊɾ ən hɛɹɹoʊd, ðə fɝoʊz hæd spæt fɔɹθ oʊnli ðə smɔləst ə spɹaʊts. ðə fild wɑz spɑɾəd wɪð ɛmpti pætʃəz wɛɹ sidz hæɾ ɪnɪksplɪkəbli ɹəfjuz tə teɪk ɹut, ən ðə plæns ðət wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ hæɾ ə jɛloʊɪʃ kæs tə ðɛm.

His field had seen better years; though the soil had been neatly plowed and harrowed, the furrows had spat forth only the smallest of sprouts. The field was spotted with empty patches where seeds had inexplicably refused to take root, and the plants that were growing had a yellowish cast to them.

ə ɡɹup ə jʌŋɡɝ mɛn wɝ pʊlɪŋ ə stʌmp fɹi fɹəm ə neɪbɝɪŋ fild, jɛt tə nɪneɪivz pɹæktəst aɪ, ðeɪ wɝn æktʃəli  tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ɛni wɝk dʌn. ðeɪ dɪdn əv ðə hɑɹnəs hʊk tə ðɛɹ ɑks, ən ðeɪ hædn lusən ðə stʌmp ɪn ði ɝθ baɪ dɪɡɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðoʊz lɛŋθs ʌv wʊd laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹæs wɝ tu staʊɾ ən smuðli wɝk tə bi ðə ʃæfs ə tulz. kɔɹɾɝstɑfs. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst ən əmjuzɪŋ dɪspleɪ - kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə fæk ðət ɹænd hæd tu hʌnʒɹəd il wɪð ɪm - bʌɾ ɪt sɛd sʌmθɪŋ. ðiz mɛn ɪkspɛktəd tʃɹʌbəl ən wɝ pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ɪt. noʊ daʊt ðeɪ kəd fil ðə stɔɹm ðɛmsɛlvz.

A group of younger men were pulling a stump free from a neighboring field, yet to Nynaeve's practiced eye, they weren't actually trying to get any work done. They didn't have the harness hooked to their ox, and they hadn't loosened the stump in the earth by digging about it. Those lengths of wood lying in the grass were too stout and smoothly worked to be the shafts of tools. Quarterstaffs. It was almost an amusing display - considering the fact that Rand had two hundred Aiel with him - but it said something. These men expected trouble and were preparing for it. No doubt they could feel the storm themselves.

ðɪs ɛɹiə, kloʊs tə tʃɹeɪd ɹuts ən wɪðɪn ɹitʃ ə tiɹ, wɑz ɹɛləɾɪvli seɪf fɹəm bændəts. ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ dʒʌs fɑɹ ɪnʌf nɔɹθ tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn skwɑbəlz bɪtwin ɪljən ən tɛɹ. ðɪs ʃʊɾə bɪn ə pleɪs wɛɹ fɑɹmɝz dɪdnt nid tə tɝn ɡʊd lʌmbɝ ɪndə kɔɹɾɝstɑfs, nɔɹ wɑtʃ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz wɪð aɪz ðəɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ətæk.

This area, close to trade routes and within reach of Tear, was relatively safe from bandits. It was also just far enough north to avoid being caught in squabbles between Illian and Tear. This should have been a place where farmers didn't need to turn good lumber into quarterstaffs, nor watch strangers with eyes that expected attack.

ðət wɛɹinɪs wəd sɝv əm wɛl wən ðə tʃɹɑləks ɹitʃt əm - əsumɪŋ ðə sintʃæn hædn kɑŋkɝɾ əm ən pɹɛst əm ɪndə ðɛɹ ɑɹmiz baɪ ðət pɔɪnt. nɪneɪiv tʌɡd əɹ bɹeɪɾ əɡɛn.

That wariness would serve them well when the Trollocs reached them - assuming the Seanchan hadn't conquered them and pressed them into their armies by that point. Nynaeve tugged her braid again.

hɝ maɪn tɝn bæk tə læn. ʃi hæd tə də sʌmθɪŋ! bʌt ɹænd wɑzn siɪŋ sɛns. ðət lɛft oʊnli kædzueɪnz mɪstɪɹiəs plæn. ful wʊmən, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə ɪkspleɪn ɪt. nɪneɪiv hæd meɪd ðə fɝst stɛp, ɔfɝɪŋ ən əlaɪəns, ən haʊ hæd kædzueɪn ɹiæktəd? wɪð pɹɪzʌmptʃəwəs ɛɹəɡəns, ʌv kɔɹs.

Her mind turned back to Lan. She had to do something! But Rand wasn't seeing sense. That left only Cadsuane's mysterious plan. Fool woman, refusing to explain it. Nynaeve had made the first step, offering an alliance, and how had Cadsuane reacted? With presumptuous arrogance, of course.

haʊ dɛɹ ʃi wɛlkəm nɪneɪiv ɪndə hɝ lɪɾəl ɡɹup ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪk ə tʃaɪld u hæd bɪn wɑndɝɪŋ ɪn ðə wʊdz!

How dare she welcome Nynaeve into her little group of Aes Sedai like a child who had been wandering in the woods!

haʊ wəd nɪneɪivz tæsk - dɪskʌvɝɪŋ wɛɹ pɛɹɪn wɑz - hɛlp læn? dʊɹɪŋ ðə pæst wik, nɪneɪiv hæd pɹɛs kædzueɪn fəɹ mɔɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, bʌt hæd feɪld. "pɝfɔɹm ðɪs tæsk wɛl, tʃaɪld,"

How would Nynaeve's task - discovering where Perrin was - help Lan? During the past week, Nynaeve had pressed Cadsuane for more information, but had failed. "Perform this task well, child,"

kædzueɪn hæd sɛd, "æn pɝhæps wi ʃæl ɡɪv jə mɔɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ. juv pɹuvən jɝsɛlf wɪlfəl ət taɪmz, ən wi kæn əv ðæt."

Cadsuane had said, "and perhaps we shall give you more responsibility in the future. You've proven yourself willful at times, and we can't have that."

nɪneɪiv saɪd. faɪn aʊt wɛɹ pɛɹɪn wɑz. haʊ wɑz ʃi səpoʊz tə də ðæt? ðə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk hæd bɪn ə lɪɾəl juz. mɛni ʌv ðɛɹ mɛn wɝ tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð pɛɹɪn, bʌt ðeɪ hædn bɪn sin fəɹ səm taɪm. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə saʊθ sʌmwɛɹ, ɔltɑɹə əɹ ɡildən, laɪkli. bʌt ðət lɛft ə lɑɹdʒ ɛɹiə tə sɝtʃ.

Nynaeve sighed. Find out where Perrin was. How was she supposed to do that? The Two Rivers folk had been of little use. Many of their men were traveling with Perrin, but they hadn't been seen for some time. They were in the south somewhere, Altara or Ghealdan, likely. But that left a large area to search.

ʃi ʃʊɾə noʊn ðət ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wəd nɑt pɹəvaɪɾ ən izi ænsɝ. kædzueɪn hæɾ ɑbviəsli ɔlɹɛɾi tʃɹaɪd ɹitʃɪŋ pɛɹɪn hɝsɛlf, ən mʌst əv feɪld. ðæts waɪ ʃid ɡɪvən ðə tæsk tə nɪneɪiv. hæd ɹænd sɛn pɛɹɪn ɑn səm sikɹət mɪʃən?

She should have known that the Two Rivers would not provide an easy answer. Cadsuane had obviously already tried reaching Perrin herself, and must have failed. That's why she'd given the task to Nynaeve. Had Rand sent Perrin on some secret mission?

"ɹænd?" ʃi sɛd.

"Rand?" she said.

hi wɑz mʌɾɝɪŋ ɹʌfli tə hɪmsɛlf.

He was muttering roughly to himself.

ʃi ʃɪvɝd. "ɹænd," ʃi sɛd mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli.

She shivered. "Rand," she said more sharply.

hi stɑp mʌɾɝɪŋ, ðən ɡlænst ət hɝ. ʃi θɔt ʃi kəd si ði æŋɡɝ hɪɾən ðɛɹ, dip wɪðɪn hɪm, ə flæʃ ʌv ənɔɪəns əɾ əɹ ɪntɝʌpʃən. ðən ɪt wɑz ɡɔn, ɹipleɪs baɪ ðə fɹaɪɾənɪŋli kul kəntʃɹoʊl. "jɛs?" hi æskt.

He stopped muttering, then glanced at her. She thought she could see the anger hidden there, deep within him, a flash of annoyance at her interruption. Then it was gone, replaced by the frighteningly cool control. "Yes?" he asked.

"du jə . . . noʊ wɛɹ pɛɹɪn ɪz?"

"Do you . . . know where Perrin is?"

"hi hæz tæsks sɛt bɪfɔɹ ɪm ən pɝfɔɹmz ðɛm," ɹænd sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. "waɪ dʒju wɪʃ tə noʊ?"

"He has tasks set before him and performs them," Rand said, turning away. "Why do you wish to know?"

bɛs nɑt tə mɛnʃən kædzueɪn. "aɪm stɪl wɝiɾ əbaʊt hɪm. ən əbaʊt mæt."

Best not to mention Cadsuane. "I'm still worried about him. And about Mat."

"ɑ," ɹænd sɛd. "ju ɑɹ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ʌnəkʌstəm tə laɪɪŋ, ɑɹən ju, nɪneɪiv?"

"Ah," Rand said. "You are particularly unaccustomed to lying, aren't you, Nynaeve?"

ʃi fɛlt əɹ feɪs flʌʃ ɪn ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. wən hæɾ i lɝn tə ɹid pipəl soʊ wɛl! "aɪ æm wɝiɾ əbaʊt hɪm, ɹænd ælθɹ," ʃi sɛd. "hi hæz ə pisfəl, ʌnəsumɪŋ neɪtʃɝ - ən ɔlweɪz dɪd lɛɾ ɪz fɹɛnz pʊʃ ɪm ɝaʊn tu mʌtʃ."

She felt her face flush in embarrassment. When had he learned to read people so well! "I am worried about him, Rand al'Thor," she said. "He has a peaceful, unassuming nature - and always did let his friends push him around too much."

ðɛɹ. lɛt ɹænd θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt.

There. Let Rand think about that.

"ʌnəsumɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd mjuzɪŋli. "jɛs, aɪ səpoʊz hiz stɪl ðæt. bʌt pisfəl? pɛɹɪn ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tu . . . pisfəl."

"Unassuming," Rand said musingly. "Yes, I suppose he is still that. But peaceful? Perrin is no longer too . . . peaceful."

soʊ hi hæd bɪn ɪn tʌtʃ wɪð pɛɹɪn ɹisənli. laɪt! haʊ hæd kædzueɪn noʊn, ən haʊ hæd nɪneɪiv mɪs ðoʊz kəmjunəkeɪʃənz? "ɹænd, ɪf juv pɛɹɪn wɝkɪŋ ɑn sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ju, ðən waɪ hæv jə kɛpt ɪt sikɹət? aɪ dɪzɝv tə - "

So he had been in touch with Perrin recently. Light! How had Cadsuane known, and how had Nynaeve missed those communications? "Rand, if you have Perrin working on something for you, then why have you kept it secret? I deserve to - "

"aɪ hævən bɪn miɾɪŋ wɪð hɪm, nɪneɪiv," ɹænd sɛd. "kɑm jɝsɛlf. ðəɹ ɑɹ sɪmpli θɪŋz ðəɾ aɪ noʊ. wəɹ kənɛktəd, pɛɹɪn, maɪsɛlf ən mæt."

"I haven't been meeting with him, Nynaeve," Rand said. "Calm yourself. There are simply things that I know. We are connected, Perrin, myself and Mat."

"haʊ? wʌt dʒju - "

"How? What do you - "

"ðæɾ ɪz ɔl əl seɪ ɑn ɪt, nɪneɪiv," ɹænd ɪntɝʌptɪd, slaɪsɪŋ ɪndə hɝ sɛntəns wɪð sɑft wɝdz.

"That is all I will say on it, Nynaeve," Rand interrupted, slicing into her sentence with soft words.

nɪneɪiv sɛɾəld bæk, ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ əɡɛn. ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ spoʊk ə biɪŋ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðɛɹ ɪmoʊʃənz, bʌɾ ɑbviəsli ðeɪ dɪdn əv tə dil wɪð ɹænd ælθɹ. nɪneɪiv kəd bi kɑm tu, ɪf ʃi wɝn ɪkspɛktəd tə mænədʒ ðə moʊs bʊlhɛɾɪd ful ʌv ə mæn u hæɾ ɛvɝ pʊɾ ɑn ə pɛɹ ə buts.

Nynaeve settled back, gritting her teeth again. The other Aes Sedai spoke of being in control of their emotions, but obviously they didn't have to deal with Rand al'Thor. Nynaeve could be calm too, if she weren't expected to manage the most bullheaded fool of a man who had ever put on a pair of boots.

ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn saɪləns fəɹ ə taɪm, ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ hæŋɪŋ əbʌv əm laɪk ə dɪstən fild ʌv ɡɹeɪmɑs pit. ðə miɾɪŋ pleɪs wɪð ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɑz ə nɪɹbaɪ kɹɔsɹoʊdz. ðeɪ cʊɾə tʃɹævəl dɝɛkli ðɛɹ, bʌt ðə meɪɾənz hæd pɹɪveɪld əpɑn ɹænd tə ɝaɪv ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns aʊɾ ən əpɹoʊtʃ mɔɹ kɛɹfəli. tʃɹævlɪŋ wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli kənvinjənt, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs. ɪf jəɹ ɛnəmiz nu wɛɹ jə wəɾ əpɪɹ, jə kəɾ oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ ən faɪn jɝsɛlf æmbʊʃt baɪ ə laɪn ʌv ɑɹtʃɝz. ivən sɛndɪŋ skaʊts θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ fɝst wɑzn əz seɪf əz tʃɹævlɪŋ tə ə spɑt wɛɹ noʊbɑdi wɑz ɪkspɛktɪŋ ju.

They rode in silence for a time, the overcast sky hanging above them like a distant field of graymoss peat. The meeting place with the Borderlanders was a nearby crossroads. They could have Traveled directly there, but the Maidens had prevailed upon Rand to arrive a short distance out and approach more carefully. Traveling was extremely convenient, but it also could be dangerous. If your enemies knew where you would appear, you could open a gateway and find yourself ambushed by a line of archers. Even sending scouts through the gateway first wasn't as safe as Traveling to a spot where nobody was expecting you.

ði il lɝnd, ən ədæptəd, kwɪkli. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ, ɹɪli. ðə weɪst wɑz tɛɹəbli ənvɹid;

The Aiel learned, and adapted, quickly. Surprising, really. The Waste was terribly unvaried;

ɛvɹi pɑɹt lʊk dʒʌst əbaʊt ðə seɪm. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd səm il ɡɑɹdz seɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ sɪməlɝ əbaʊt ðə wɛtlænz.

every part looked just about the same. Of course, she had overheard some Aiel guards saying something similar about the wetlands.

ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ kɹɔsɹoʊdz hædn bɪn ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn jɪɹz. ɪf vɛɹɪn əɹ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ bɹaʊn sɪstɝz hæd bɪn ðɛɹ, ðeɪd laɪkli hæv bɪn eɪbəl tə ɪkspleɪn ɪɡzækli waɪ. ɔl nɪneɪiv nu wɑz ðət ðə kɪŋdəm wɪtʃ hæd wʌns hɛl ðɪs læn hæd fɔlən lɔŋ əɡoʊ, ən ði oʊnli ɹɛmnənt wɑz ði ɪndɪpɛndən sɪɾi ʌv fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. ðə wil ə taɪm tɝnd. ðə moʊst ɡɹæn ə kɪŋdəmz fɛl, ɹʌstəɾ ən ɪvɛntʃəwəli tʃeɪnʒd ɪndə leɪzi filz, ɹuld oʊnli baɪ fɑɹmɝz dɪtɝmən tə ɡɹoʊ ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɡʊd kɹɑp ə bɑɹli. ɪt hæd hæpən tə meɪnɛðɝən, ən ɪt hæd hæpən hɪɹ. ɡɹeɪt haɪweɪz ðət hæd wʌns tʃɹænspɔɹɾəd lidʒənz naʊ dwɪndəl tə əbskjʊɹ kʌntʃɹi ɹoʊdz ɪn niɾ ə meɪntənəns.

This particular crossroads hadn't been important in years. If Verin or one of the other Brown sisters had been there, they'd likely have been able to explain exactly why. All Nynaeve knew was that the kingdom which had once held this land had fallen long ago, and the only remnant was the independent city of Far Madding. The Wheel of Time turned. The most grand of kingdoms fell, rusted and eventually changed into lazy fields, ruled only by farmers determined to grow a particularly good crop of barley. It had happened to Manetheren, and it had happened here. Great highways that had once transported legions now dwindled to obscure country roads in need of maintenance.

əz ðeɪ kəntɪnjud, nɪneɪiv lɛt munlaɪt fɔl bæk fɹəm ɹændz pəzɪʃən. ðət pleɪst əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɪɹ nɛɹɪʃmə, wɪð ɪz dɑɹk, bɹeɪɾɪd hɛɹ, bɛlz tɪŋkəlɪŋ ɑn ði ɛnz. hi wɔɹ blæk, laɪk moʊst æʃəmən, ən ðə sɔɹɾ ən dʒɹæɡən twɪŋkəld ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ. hid tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ðə mʌnθs sɪns biɪŋ bɑndəɾ əz ə wɔɹɾɝ. ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lʊk əɾ ɪm ən si ə bɔɪ. ðɪs wɑz ə mæn, wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪs ʌv ə soʊlʒɝ, ðə kɛɹfəl aɪz ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ. ə mæn u hæd sin dɛθ ən fɔt fɔɹseɪkən.

As they continued, Nynaeve let Moonlight fall back from Rand's position. That placed her riding near Narishma, with his dark, braided hair, bells tinkling on the ends. He wore black, like most Asha'man, and the Sword and Dragon twinkled on his collar. He'd changed in the months since being bonded as a Warder. She could no longer look at him and see a boy. This was a man, with the grace of a soldier, the careful eyes of a Warder. A man who had seen death and fought Forsaken.

"jɔɹ ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ, nɛɹɪʃmə," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "du juv ɛni aɪdiə waɪ ði ʌðɝz lɛf ðɛɹ poʊsts?"

"You're a Borderlander, Narishma," Nynaeve said. "Do you have any idea why the others left their posts?"

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, skænɪŋ ðə lændskeɪp. "aɪ wɑz ə kɑblɝz sʌn, nɪneɪiv sədaɪ. aɪ noʊ nɑt ðə weɪz ə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "bɪsaɪdz, aɪm nɑɾ ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ ɛnimɔɹ." ði ɪmpləkeɪʃən wɑz klɪɹ. hi wəd pɹətɛkt ɹænd, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ʌðɝ ælidʒiænsɪz tʌɡd ət hɪm. ə vɛɹi wɔɹɾɝ- laɪk weɪ ʌv θɔt.

He shook his head, scanning the landscape. "I was a cobbler's son, Nynaeve Sedai. I know not the ways of lords and ladies." He hesitated. "Besides, I'm not a Borderlander anymore." The implication was clear. He would protect Rand, no matter what other allegiances tugged at him. A very Warder- like way of thought.

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd sloʊli. "du juv ɛni aɪdiə wʌt wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪntu?"

Nynaeve nodded slowly. "Do you have any idea what we're riding into?"

"ðeɪl kip ðɛɹ wɝd," nɛɹɪʃmə sɛd. "eɪ bɔɹɾɝləndɝ wəd sunɝ daɪ ðən bɹeɪk ɪz wɝd. ðeɪ pɹɑməs tə sɛn ə dɛləɡeɪʃən tə mit wɪð ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. ðəl də dʒʌs ðæt. aɪ wɪʃ wid bɪn əlaʊd tə bɹɪŋ əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ."

"They'll keep their word," Narishma said. "A Borderlander would sooner die than break his word. They promised to send a delegation to meet with the Lord Dragon. They'll do just that. I wish we'd been allowed to bring our Aes Sedai, though."

ɹɪpɔɹts hɛl ðət ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ ɑɹmi ɪnkluɾəd θɝtin ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə deɪnʒɝəs nʌmbɝ: ðə nʌmbɝ niɾəd tə stɪl ə wʊmən əɹ dʒɛntəl ə mæn. θɝtin wɪmən ɪn ə sɝkəl kəd ʃil ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə tʃænlɝz. ɹænd hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd ðət ðə dɛləɡeɪʃən ðət keɪm tə miɾ ɪm ɪnklud noʊ mɔɹ ðən fɔɹ ə ðoʊz θɝtin ɛɛs sədaɪ; ɪn ɹɪtɝn, hi pɹɑməs tə bɹɪŋ noʊ mɔɹ ðən fɔɹ tʃænlɝz.

Reports held that the Borderlander army included thirteen Aes Sedai. A dangerous number: the number needed to still a woman or gentle a man. Thirteen women in a circle could shield the most powerful of channelers. Rand had insisted that the delegation that came to meet him include no more than four of those thirteen Aes Sedai; in return, he promised to bring no more than four channelers.

tu æʃəmən - nɛɹɪʃmə ən nf - nɪneɪiv ən ɹænd hɪmsɛlf.

Two Asha'man - Narishma and Naeff - Nynaeve and Rand himself.

mɛɹaɪs ən ði ʌðɝz hæd θɹoʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪkwɪvələn ʌv ə fɪt - ɪɾ ɪnvɑlvd ə lɑɾ ə daʊntɝn lɪps ən kwɛstʃənz laɪk "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jə wɑnə də ðæt?" - wən ɹænd hæd fɔɹbɪɾən əm tə kʌm.

Merise and the others had thrown the Aes Sedai equivalent of a fit - it involved a lot of downturned lips and questions like "Are you certain you want to do that?" - when Rand had forbidden them to come.

nɪneɪiv noʊɾəd nɛɹɪʃməz tɛns pɑstʃɝ. "ju doʊn lʊk əz ɪf jə tʃɹʌs ðɛm."

Nynaeve noted Narishma's tense posture. "You don't look as if you trust them."

"eɪ bɔɹɾɝləndɝz pleɪs ɪz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ," nɛɹɪʃmə sɛd. "aɪ wɑz ə kɑblɝz sʌn, ən jɛɾ aɪ wɑz tʃɹeɪnd wɪð ðə sɔɹd, spɪɹ, baʊ, æks ən slɪŋ. ivən bɪfɔɹ dʒɔɪnɪŋ ði æʃəmən, aɪ kəd bɛs fɔɹ aʊɾ ə faɪv tʃɹeɪn sʌðɝn soʊlʒɝz ɪn ə duəl. wi lɪv tə dɪfɛnd. ən jɛt ðeɪ lɛft. naʊ, ʌv ɔl taɪmz. wɪð θɝtin ɛɛs sədaɪ." hi ɡlænst əɾ əɹ wɪð ðoʊz dɑɹk aɪz ə hɪz. "aɪ wɑnə tʃɹʌs ðɛm. aɪ noʊ ðɛm fəɹ ɡʊd pipəl. bʌt ɡʊd pipəl kən də ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən mɛn u kən tʃænəl ɑɹ ɪnvɑlvd."

"A Borderlander's place is guarding the Border," Narishma said. "I was a cobbler's son, and yet I was trained with the sword, spear, bow, axe and sling. Even before joining the Asha'man, I could best four out of five trained southern soldiers in a duel. We live to defend. And yet they left. Now, of all times. With thirteen Aes Sedai." He glanced at her with those dark eyes of his. "I want to trust them. I know them for good people. But good people can do the wrong thing. Particularly when men who can channel are involved."

nɪneɪiv fɛl saɪlənt. nɛɹɪʃmə hæɾ ə pɔɪnt, ðoʊ wʌt kɑz wəd ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz əv tə hɑɹm ɹænd? ðeɪd fɔt ði ɛnkɹoʊtʃmən ə ðə blaɪɾ ən ɪts ʃæɾoʊzpɔn fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz, ən ðə stʃɹʌɡəl əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz ɪmpɹɪntɪɾ ɑn ðɛɹ vɛɹi soʊlz. ðeɪ wʊdn tɝn əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Nynaeve fell silent. Narishma had a point, though what cause would the Borderlanders have to harm Rand? They'd fought the encroachment of the Blight and its Shadowspawn for centuries, and the struggle against the Dark One was imprinted on their very souls. They wouldn't turn against the Dragon Reborn.

ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz hæɾ ə spɛʃəl ɑnɝ əbaʊt ðɛm. ɪt kəd bi fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ, tʃɹu, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz u ðeɪ wɝ. lænz ɹɛvɝəns fəɹ ɪz hoʊmlænd - pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən mɛni ʌðɝ mɔlkɪɹi hæɾ əbændən ðɛɹ aɪdɛntəɾi - wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt ʃi lʌvd əbaʊt hɪm. oʊ, læn. əl faɪn sʌmwʌn tə hɛlp ju. aɪ woʊn lɛt jə ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz dʒɔz əloʊn.

The Borderlanders had a special honor about them. It could be frustrating, true, but it was who they were. Lan's reverence for his homeland - particularly when many other Malkieri had abandoned their identity - was part of what she loved about him. Oh, Lan. I'll find someone to help you. I won't let you ride into the Shadow's jaws alone.

əz ðeɪ nɪɹɾ ə smɔl ɡɹin hɪl, sɛvɹəl il ɹɪtɝn fɹəm skaʊɾɪŋ. ɹænd pʊl ðə ɡɹup tə ə hɔlt, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ-klæd skaʊts tə pæɾ ʌp tə hɪm, sɛvɹəl wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹɛd hɛdbænz mɑɹkt wɪð ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə skaʊts wɝnt wɪndɪd, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðət ðeɪd ɹʌn ɔl ðə weɪ əhɛd tə ðə miɾɪŋ pleɪs ən ðən bæk.

As they neared a small green hill, several Aiel returned from scouting. Rand pulled the group to a halt, waiting for the cadin'sor-clad scouts to pad up to him, several wearing the red headbands marked with the ancient symbol of the Aes Sedai. The scouts weren't winded, despite the fact that they'd run all the way ahead to the meeting place and then back.

ɹænd lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. "dɪd ðeɪ də əz aɪ æskt? dɪd ðeɪ bɹɪŋ noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu hʌnʒɹəd mɛn, noʊ mɔɹ ðən fɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

Rand leaned forward in his saddle. "Did they do as I asked? Did they bring no more than two hundred men, no more than four Aes Sedai?"

"jɛs, ɹænd ælθɹ," sɛd wʌn ə ðə skaʊts. "jɛs, ðeɪ kɛp tə jəɹ ɹɪkwaɪɹməns ædmɝəbli.

"Yes, Rand al'Thor," said one of the scouts. "Yes, they kept to your requirements admirably.

ðeɪv ɡɹeɪɾ ɑnɝ."

They have great honor."

nɪneɪiv ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ il bɹæn ə hjumɝ ɪn ðə toʊn ə ðə mænz ɹɪspɑns.

Nynaeve recognized the strange Aiel brand of humor in the tone of the man's response.

"wʌt?" ɹænd æskt.

"What?" Rand asked.

"wʌn mæn, ɹænd ælθɹ," ði il skaʊt sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz ɔl ðət ðɛɹ 'dɛləɡeɪʃən' kənsɪsts ʌv. hiz ə ʃɔɹt lɪɾəl θɪŋ ʌv ə mæn, ðoʊ hi lʊks laɪk i noʊz haʊ tə dæns ðə spɪɹz. ðə kɹɔsɹoʊdz ɪz bɪhaɪn ðɪs hɪl."

"One man, Rand al'Thor," the Aiel scout said. "That is all that their 'delegation' consists of. He's a short little thing of a man, though he looks like he knows how to dance the spears. The crossroads is behind this hill."

nɪneɪiv lʊkt əhɛd. ɪndid, naʊ ðət ʃi nu tə lʊk, ʃi kəd si ənʌðɝ ɹoʊd ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə saʊθ, pɹəzuməbli miɾɪŋ wɪð ðɛɹz dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə hɪl.

Nynaeve looked ahead. Indeed, now that she knew to look, she could see another road running up from the south, presumably meeting with theirs just beyond the hill.

"wʌt mænɝ ə tʃɹæp ɪz ðɪs?" nf æskt, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd ɹænd, hɪz lin, wɔɹiɝz feɪs kənsɝnd. "æn æmbʊʃ?"

"What manner of trap is this?" Naeff asked, riding up beside Rand, his lean, warrior's face concerned. "An ambush?"

ɹænd hɛld ʌp ə hæn fəɹ saɪləns. hi kɪkt ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ ɪndə moʊʃən, ən ðə skaʊts kɛpt ʌp wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝɾ ə kəmpleɪnt. nɪneɪiv wɑz nɪɹli lɛf bɪhaɪnd; munlaɪt wɑz ə fɑɹ mɔɹ plæsəɾ ænəməl ðən ʃi wʊɾə tʃoʊzən fəɹ hɝsɛlf. ʃiɾ əv wɝdz wɪð ðə steɪbəl mæstɝ wən ʃi ɹɪtɝn tə tɛɹ.

Rand held up a hand for silence. He kicked his gelding into motion, and the scouts kept up without a word of complaint. Nynaeve was nearly left behind; Moonlight was a far more placid animal than she would have chosen for herself. She'd have words with the stable master when she returned to Tear.

ðeɪ ɹaʊndəd ðə hɪlsaɪd, faɪndɪŋ ə dʌsti skwɛɹ ʌv ɡɹaʊnd, skɑɹd baɪ oʊl faɪɹɛpɪts wɛɹ kæɹəvænz hæd stɑp fəɹ ðə naɪt. ə ɹoʊdweɪ smɔlɝ ðən ðə wʌn ðeɪd bɪn juzɪŋ twɪstəɾ ʌp tə ðə nɔɹθ ən daʊn tə ðə saʊθ. ə sɑlətɛɹi ʃaɪnɝən mæn stʊɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, wɛɹ ɹoʊdz mɛt, wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ pɹəsɛʃən. hɪz ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ hʌŋ lus ɝaʊn ə lin feɪs wɪtʃ kɑmpləmɛntɪɾ ɪz wɪɹi bɪld. hɪz ɹaʊn feɪs wɑz laɪnd wɪð mɑɹks ʌv eɪdʒ; hɪz aɪz wɝ smɔl, ən i sim tə bi skwɪntɪŋ.

They rounded the hillside, finding a dusty square of ground, scarred by old firepits where caravans had stopped for the night. A roadway smaller than the one they'd been using twisted up to the north and down to the south. A solitary Shienaran man stood in the center, where roads met, watching the oncoming procession. His shoulder-length gray hair hung loose around a lean face which complemented his wiry build. His round face was lined with marks of age; his eyes were small, and he seemed to be squinting.

hʊɹɪn? ʃi θɔt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz. nɪneɪiv hædn sin ðə θif-teɪkɝ sɪns hiɾ əkʌmpəniɾ əɹ ən ə ɡɹup ʌv ʌðɝz bæk tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ fɑloʊɪŋ ði ɪvɛns ət fɑlm.

Hurin? she thought with surprise. Nynaeve hadn't seen the thief-taker since he'd accompanied her and a group of others back to the White Tower following the events at Falme.

ɹænd ɹeɪn ɪn ɪz hɔɹs, əlaʊɪŋ nɪneɪiv ən ði æʃəmən tə kætʃ ʌp. il fæn aʊt laɪk livz bloʊn bɪfɔɹ ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪnd, teɪkɪŋ ʌp wɑtʃfəl pəzɪʃənz ɝaʊn ðə kɹɔsɹoʊdz. ʃi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən ðət boʊθ ə ði æʃəmən hæd siz ðə sɔɹs, ən laɪkli ɹænd hæɾ əz wɛl.

Rand reined in his horse, allowing Nynaeve and the Asha'man to catch up. Aiel fanned out like leaves blown before a gust of wind, taking up watchful positions around the crossroads. She was fairly certain that both of the Asha'man had seized the Source, and likely Rand had as well.

hʊɹɪn ʃʌfəld ənkʌmftəbli. hi lʊk mʌtʃ əz nɪneɪiv ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɪm. ə tæd mɔɹ ɡɹeɪ ɪn ðə hɛɹ, bʌt wɛɹɪŋ ðə seɪm sɪmpəl bɹaʊn kloʊðɪŋ, wɪð ə sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ ən ə ʃɔɹtsɔɝɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst. hi hæd taɪɾ ə hɔɹs tə ə fɔlən lɔɡ nɪɹbaɪ. ði il wɑtʃt ɪt səspɪʃəsli, əz ʌðɝz maɪt wɑtʃ ə pæk ʌv ɡɑɹd dɑɡz.

Hurin shuffled uncomfortably. He looked much as Nynaeve remembered him. A tad more gray in the hair, but wearing the same simple brown clothing, with a sword-breaker and a shortsword at his waist. He had tied a horse to a fallen log nearby. The Aiel watched it suspiciously, as others might watch a pack of guard dogs.

"waɪ, lɔɹd ɹænd!" hʊɹɪn kɔld, vɔɪs ənivən. "ɪɾ ɪz ju! wɛl, juv sɝɾənli kʌm ʌp ɪn ðə wɝld, aɪ mʌst seɪ. ɡʊd tə - "

"Why, Lord Rand!" Hurin called, voice uneven. "It is you! Well, you've certainly come up in the world, I must say. Good to - "

hi kʌɾ ɔf əz i wɑz ɹeɪz fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi meɪɾ ən "ɝk" ʌv sɝpɹaɪz, biɪŋ tɝn ɑn ənsin wivz ʌv ɛɹ. nɪneɪiv səpɹɛst ə ʃɪvɝ. wəd siɪŋ mɛn tʃænəl ɛvɝ stɑp bɑðɝɪŋ hɝ?

He cut off as he was raised from the ground. He made an "urk" of surprise, being turned on unseen weaves of Air. Nynaeve suppressed a shiver. Would seeing men channel ever stop bothering her?

"hu tʃeɪst æftɝ jə ən mi, hʊɹɪn," ɹænd kɔld, "ðə taɪm wən wi wɝ tʃɹæpt ɪn ðət dɪstənt ʃædoʊ lænd? wʌt næʃənæləɾi ʌv mɛn dɪɾ aɪ fɛl wɪð ðə baʊ?"

"Who chased after you and me, Hurin," Rand called, "the time when we were trapped in that distant shadow land? What nationality of men did I fell with the bow?"

"mɛn?" hʊɹɪn æskt, vɔɪs ɔlmoʊst ə skwɔk. "lɔɹd ɹænd, ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɛn ɪn ðət pleɪs! nʌn ðət wi mɛt, bɪɑn leɪɾi səlin, ðəɾ ɪz. ɔl aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɑɹ ðoʊz fɹɑɡ bists, ðə seɪm wʌnz foʊk seɪ ðoʊz sintʃæn ɹaɪd!"

"Men?" Hurin asked, voice almost a squawk. "Lord Rand, there were no men in that place! None that we met, beyond Lady Selene, that is. All I remember are those frog beasts, the same ones folk say those Seanchan ride!"

ɹænd spʌn hʊɹɪn ɝaʊn ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪm wɪð koʊld aɪz. ðən i ɝdʒd ɪz maʊn kloʊsɝ.

Rand spun Hurin around in the Air, regarding him with cold eyes. Then he urged his mount closer.

nɪneɪiv ən ði æʃəmən dɪɾ əz wɛl.

Nynaeve and the Asha'man did as well.

"ju doʊn bɪliv ðəɾ aɪm mi, lɔɹd ɹænd?" hʊɹɪn æskt əz i hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ.

"You don't believe that I'm me, Lord Rand?" Hurin asked as he hung in the air.

"aɪ teɪk vɛɹi lɪɾəl əz ɪts pɹizɛntəd tə mi, ðiz deɪz," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ əsum ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz sɛn jə kəz ʌv əɹ fəmɪljɛɹəɾi?"

"I take very little as it is presented to me, these days," Rand said. "I assume the Borderlanders sent you because of our familiarity?"

hʊɹɪn nɑɾəd, swɛɾɪŋ. nɪneɪiv fɛlt ə stæb ə pɪɾi fəɹ ðə mæn. hi wɑz æbsəlutli dɪvoʊɾəd tə ɹænd. ðeɪ hæd spɛn ə lɑɾ ə taɪm təɡɛðɝ, tʃeɪsɪŋ daʊn feɪn ən ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ɑn ðə ɹɪtɝn tʃɹɪp tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ʃid sɛldəm bɪn eɪbəl tə stɑp hʊɹɪn fɹəm ɡɑsəpɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs əɹ ðət ɡɹæn fit ðət ɹænd hæɾ əkɑmplɪʃt. biɪŋ tʃɹiɾəd ðɪs weɪ baɪ ðə mæn i aɪɾəlaɪzd wɑz pɹɑbli vɛɹi ənsɛɾəlɪŋ fəɹ ðə lin θif-teɪkɝ.

Hurin nodded, sweating. Nynaeve felt a stab of pity for the man. He was absolutely devoted to Rand. They had spent a lot of time together, chasing down Fain and the Horn of Valere. On the return trip to Tar Valon, she'd seldom been able to stop Hurin from gossiping about this or that grand feat that Rand had accomplished. Being treated this way by the man he idolized was probably very unsettling for the lean thief-taker.

"waɪ oʊnli ju?" ɹænd æskt kwaɪətli.

"Why only you?" Rand asked quietly.

"wɛl," hʊɹɪn sɛd, saɪɪŋ. "ðeɪ dɪd tɛl jə - " hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, simɪŋ dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ sʌmθɪŋ.

"Well," Hurin said, sighing. "They did tell you - " He hesitated, seeming distracted by something.

hi snɪft ɑɾəbli. "naʊ ðət . . . ðæts stʃɹeɪnʒ. nɛvɝ smɛl ðət bɪfɔɹ."

He sniffed audibly. "Now that . . . that's strange. Never smelled that before."

"wʌt?" ɹænd æskt.

"What?" Rand asked.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," hʊɹɪn sɛd. "ði ɛɹ . . . ɪt smɛlz laɪk ə lɑɾ ə dɛθ, ə lɑɾ ə vaɪələns, oʊnli nɑt.

"I don't know," Hurin said. "The air . . . it smells like a lot of death, a lot of violence, only not.

ɪts dɑɹkɝ. mɔɹ tɛɹəbəl." hi ʃʌɾɝəd vɪzəbli. hʊɹɪnz əbɪləɾi tə smɛl vaɪələns wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz ɑɾətiz ðət ðə taʊɝ kʊdn ɪkspleɪn. nɑt sʌmθɪŋ ɹɪleɪɾɪd tə ðə paʊɝ, jɛɾ ɑbviəsli nɑt kwaɪt nætʃɹəl iðɝ.

It's darker. More terrible." He shuddered visibly. Hurin's ability to smell violence was one of those oddities that the Tower couldn't explain. Not something related to the Power, yet obviously not quite natural either.

ɹænd dɪdn sim tə kɛɹ wʌt hʊɹɪn smɛld. "tɛl mi waɪ ðeɪ sɛn oʊnli ju, hʊɹɪn."

Rand didn't seem to care what Hurin smelled. "Tell me why they sent only you, Hurin."

"aɪ wɑz seɪɪŋ, lɔɹd ɹænd. si, ðɪs hɪɹ, wɝ tə dɪskʌs tɝmz."

"I was saying, Lord Rand. See, this here, we're to discuss terms."

"tɝmz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ jəɹ ɑɹmiz muvɪŋ bæk wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ," ɹænd sɛd.

"Terms regarding your armies moving back where they belong," Rand said.

"noʊ, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛɾ ənkʌmftəbli. "tɝmz fəɹ sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ə ɹil miɾɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. ðət pɑɹɾ ɪn ðɛɹ lɛɾɝ wɑz kaɪndə veɪɡ, aɪ ɡɛs. ðeɪ sɛd jə maɪt bi æŋɡɹi tə faɪn oʊnli mi hɪɹ."

"No, Lord Rand," Hurin said uncomfortably. "Terms for setting up a real meeting with them. That part in their letter was kind of vague, I guess. They said you might be angry to find only me here."

"ðeɪ wɝ ɹɔŋ," ɹænd sɛd, vɔɪs sɑftɝ. nɪneɪiv faʊn hɝsɛlf stʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə hɪɹ hɪm, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd.

"They were wrong," Rand said, voice softer. Nynaeve found herself straining to hear him, leaning forward.

"aɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fil æŋɡɝ, hʊɹɪn," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪt sɝvz mi noʊ jusfəl fʌŋkʃən. waɪ wəd wi nid 'tɝmz' tə mit təɡɛðɝ? aɪ pɹəzum ðət maɪ ɔfɝ tə bɹɪŋ oʊnli ə smɔl fɔɹs wəd bi æksɛptəbəl."

"I no longer feel anger, Hurin," Rand said. "It serves me no useful function. Why would we need 'terms' to meet together? I presumed that my offer to bring only a small force would be acceptable."

"wɛl, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd, "ju si, ðeɪ ɹɪli wɑnə mit wɪð ju. aɪ min, wi keɪm ɔl ðɪs weɪ - mɑɹtʃt θɹu ðə blʌɾi wɪntɝ ɪtsɛlf, maɪ pɑɹɾən, ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə blʌɾi wɪntɝ! ən ə bæd wʌn, ɔlðoʊ ɪt tʊk ə lɔŋ taɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ tə ʌs. ɛniweɪz, wi dɪd ðət kʌmɪŋ fəɹ ju, lɔɹd ɹænd. soʊ jə si, ðeɪ wɑnə mit wɪð ju. vɛɹi bædli."

"Well, Lord Rand," Hurin said, "you see, they really want to meet with you. I mean, we came all this way - marched through the bloody winter itself, my pardon, Aes Sedai. But it was the bloody winter! And a bad one, although it took a long time getting to us. Anyways, we did that coming for you, Lord Rand. So you see, they want to meet with you. Very badly."

"bʌt?"

"But?"

"bʌt, wɛl, læs taɪm jə wɝ ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz - "

"But, well, last time you were in Far Madding there was - "

ɹænd hɛld ʌp ə fɪŋɡɝ. hʊɹɪn kwaɪəɾəd, ən ɔl ɡɹu stɪl. ivən ðə hɔɹsəz sim tə hoʊl ðɛɹ bɹɛθs.

Rand held up a finger. Hurin quieted, and all grew still. Even the horses seemed to hold their breaths.

"ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz ɑɹ ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ?" ɹænd æskt.

"The Borderlanders are in Far Madding?" Rand asked.

"jɛs, lɔɹd ɹænd."

"Yes, Lord Rand."

"ðeɪ wɑnə mit wɪð mi ðɛɹ?"

"They want to meet with me there?"

"jɛs, lɔɹd ɹænd. jəl əv tə kʌm ɪnsaɪd ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə ðə ɡɑɹɾiən, jə si, ən - "

"Yes, Lord Rand. You'll have to come inside the protection of the Guardian, you see, and - "

ɹænd weɪvd ə kɝt hænd, kʌɾɪŋ ɔf hʊɹɪn. ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən ɪmiɾiətli. ɪt dɪdn əpɪɹ tə lid tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ; ɪt dʒʌs lɛd bæk ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns, tə ðə ɹoʊd wɛɹ ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm bɪfɔɹ.

Rand waved a curt hand, cutting off Hurin. A gateway opened immediately. It didn't appear to lead to Far Madding, however; it just led back a short distance, to the road where Rand and the others had been riding a short time before.

ɹænd ɹilis hʊɹɪn, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ fəɹ ði il tə lɛt ðə mæn maʊnt, ðən muv teɪdeɪʃɝ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn? ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls fɑloʊd. wʌns θɹu, ɹænd kɹieɪɾəd ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ, ðɪs wʌn oʊpənɪŋ ɪndə ə smɔl wʊɾɪd hɑloʊ. nɪneɪiv θɔt ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪt; ðɪs wɑz wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd stɑp fɑloʊɪŋ ðɛɹ vɪzət tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ wɪð kædzueɪn.

Rand released Hurin, gesturing for the Aiel to let the man mount, then moved Tai'daishar through the gateway. What was going on? Everyone else followed. Once through, Rand created another gateway, this one opening into a small wooded hollow. Nynaeve thought she recognized it; this was where they had stopped following their visit to Far Madding with Cadsuane.

waɪ ðə fɝst ɡeɪtweɪ? nɪneɪiv θɔt, kənfjuzd. ən ðən ɪɾ əkɝd tə hɝ. wʌn dɪdnt nid tə lɝn ən ɛɹiə tə tʃɹævəl ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns fɹəm ɪt - ən tʃɹævlɪŋ tə ə pleɪs tɔt sʌmwʌn ðət loʊkeɪʃən wɛl ɪnʌf tə kɹieɪt ɡeɪtweɪz fɹəm ɪt.

Why the first gateway? Nynaeve thought, confused. And then it occurred to her. One didn't need to learn an area to Travel a short distance from it - and Traveling to a place taught someone that location well enough to create gateways from it.

soʊ baɪ tʃɹævlɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt hɑp fɝst, ɹænd mɛmɝaɪz ðə loʊkeɪʃən wɛl ɪnʌf tə kɹieɪt ɡeɪtweɪz wɛɹɛvɝ i wɑntəd - waɪl skɪpɪŋ ðə taɪm niɾəd tə lɝn ði ɛɹiə! ɪt wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli klɛvɝ, ən nɪneɪiv fɛl hɝsɛlf blʌʃɪŋ ðət ʃi hædn sin ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi bɪfɔɹ. haʊ lɔŋ hæd ɹænd noʊn ə ðɪs tʃɹɪk? hæd mɛmɹi ʌv ɪt kʌm fɹəm ðət . . . vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd?

So by Traveling a short hop first, Rand memorized the location well enough to create gateways wherever he wanted - while skipping the time needed to learn the area! It was extremely clever, and Nynaeve felt herself blushing that she hadn't seen the possibility before. How long had Rand known of this trick? Had memory of it come from that . . . voice in his head?

ɹænd ɹoʊd teɪdeɪʃɝ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɑloʊ, ðə hɔɹsəz hʊvz stɝɪŋ fɔlən livz əz i wɝkt ɪz weɪ θɹu ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ. nɪneɪiv fɑloʊd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɝdʒ əɹ dɑsəl mɛɹ tə kip ʌp wɪð ɹænd. ðət steɪbələmæstɝ wɑz gɑnə hɪɹ fɹəm əɹ fəɹ sɝɾən. hɪz ɪɹz wəd bɝn wən ʃi wɑz θɹu wɪð hɪm!

Rand rode Tai'daishar out into the hollow, the horse's hooves stirring fallen leaves as he worked his way through the underbrush. Nynaeve followed, trying to urge her docile mare to keep up with Rand. That stablemaster was going to hear from her for certain. His ears would burn when she was through with him!

hʊɹɪn tʃɹɑɾəd ɪz hɔɹs aʊɾ əz wɛl, ən ði il loʊpt əlɔŋ, sʌɾəli kipɪŋ ɪm sɝaʊndəd. ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ feɪsəz veɪld, spɪɹz əɹ baʊz ɪn hænd. pæs ðə tʃɹiz ən ʌndɝbɹʌʃ, ɹænd stɑp teɪdeɪʃɝ, lʊkɪŋ əkɹɔs ði oʊpən mɛdoʊ təwɔɹd ði eɪntʃən sɪɾi ʌv fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ.

Hurin trotted his horse out as well, and the Aiel loped along, subtly keeping him surrounded. They had their faces veiled, spears or bows in hand. Past the trees and underbrush, Rand stopped Tai'daishar, looking across the open meadow toward the ancient city of Far Madding.

ɪt wɑzn lɑɹdʒ, nɑt baɪ ðə mɛʒɝ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz. nɔɹ wɑz ɪt bjuɾəfəl, nɑt wən kəmpɛɹd wɪð ði oʊɡiɝ-bɪlt wʌndɝz nɪneɪiv hæd sin. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɪɡ ɪnʌf, ən ɪt wɑz sɝɾənli hoʊm tə faɪn ɑɹkətɛktʃɝ ən eɪntʃən ɹɛlɪks. sɛɾ əpɑn ən aɪlən ɪn ə leɪk, ɪt wɑz æktʃəli  feɪnli ɹɛmənɪsən ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. θɹi bɹɔd bɹɪdʒəz kɹɔs ðə kɑm wɔɾɝz, ən wɝ ði oʊnli minz ʌv ɛntɝɪŋ ðə sɪɾi.

It wasn't large, not by the measure of the Great Cities. Nor was it beautiful, not when compared with the Ogier-built wonders Nynaeve had seen. But it was big enough, and it was certainly home to fine architecture and ancient relics. Set upon an island in a lake, it was actually faintly reminiscent of Tar Valon. Three broad bridges crossed the calm waters, and were the only means of entering the city.

ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ ɑɹmi wɑz ɪnkæmpt ɝaʊn ðə leɪk, pɝhæps kʌvɝɪŋ mɔɹ ɡɹaʊn ðən fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɪtsɛlf. nɪneɪiv kaʊntəd dʌzənz ə dɪfɹən pɛnənz mɑɹkɪŋ dʌzənz ə dɪfɹən haʊsəz.

A very large army was encamped around the lake, perhaps covering more ground than Far Madding itself. Nynaeve counted dozens of different pennons marking dozens of different houses.

ðəɹ wɝ laɪnz əpɑn laɪnz ə hɔɹsəz, ən tɛns laɪk ɹoʊz ə sʌmɝ kɹɑps, kɛɹfəli plæntəɾ ən ɔɹɡənaɪzd, əweɪɾɪŋ hɑɹvəst. ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ ɑɹmi.

There were lines upon lines of horses, and tents like rows of summer crops, carefully planted and organized, awaiting harvest. The Borderlander army.

"aɪv hɝɾ ə ðɪs pleɪs," nf sɛd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp, kloʊs-kɹɑpt, dɑɹk bɹaʊn hɛɹ ɹʌfəlɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. hi nɛɹoʊɾ ɪz aɪz, ɹɛktæŋɡjəlɝ feɪs dɪsæɾəsfaɪd. "ɪts laɪk ə stɛɾɪŋ, oʊnli nɑɾ əz seɪf."

"I've heard of this place," Naeff said, riding up, close-cropped, dark brown hair ruffling in the wind. He narrowed his eyes, rectangular face dissatisfied. "It's like a stedding, only not as safe."

fɑɹ mæɾɪŋz mæsɪv tɛɹæŋɡɹil - noʊn əz ðə ɡɑɹɾiən - kɹieɪɾəd ɪnvɪzəbəl pɹətɛktɪv bʌbəlz ðət blɑk pipəl fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðət kəd bi wɝkt ɝaʊn θɹu ðə jus ʌv ə vɛɹi spɛʃəlaɪz tɛɹæŋɡɹil, wʌn ʌv wɪtʃ nɪneɪiv hæpən tə bi wɛɹɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪt wəd hɛlp oʊnli slaɪtli.

Far Madding's massive ter'angreal - known as the Guardian - created invisible protective bubbles that blocked people from touching the One Power. That could be worked around through the use of a very specialized ter'angreal, one of which Nynaeve happened to be wearing. But it would help only slightly.

ði ɑɹmi lʊkt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə bi wɪðɪn ðə bʌbəl ðət pɹɪvɛntɪd mɛn fɹəm tʃænəlɪŋ, wɪtʃ ɪkstɛndəɾ əbaʊɾ ə maɪl aʊɾ ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi.

The army looked close enough to be within the bubble that prevented men from channeling, which extended about a mile out around the city.

"ðeɪ wɪl noʊ wiv kʌm," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, aɪz nɛɹoʊd. "ðeɪl əv bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪt. ðeɪ ɪkspɛk mi tə ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðɛɹ bɑks."

"They will know we've come," Rand said softly, eyes narrowed. "They'll have been waiting for it. They expect me to ride into their box."

"bɑks?" nɪneɪiv æsk hɛzɪɾəntli.

"Box?" Nynaeve asked hesitantly.

"ðə sɪɾi ɪz ə bɑks," ɹænd sɛd. "ðə hoʊl sɪɾi ən ði ɛɹiə ɹaʊn ɪt. ðeɪ wɑn mi wɛɹ ðeɪ kən kəntʃɹoʊl mi, bʌt ðeɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd. noʊbɑdi kəntʃɹoʊlz mi. nɑɾ ɛnimɔɹ. aɪv hæɾ ɪnʌf ə bɑksəz ən pɹɪzənz, ʌv tʃeɪnz ən ɹoʊps. nɛvɝ əɡɛn wɪl aɪ pʊt maɪsɛlf ɪndə ðə paʊɝ ʌv ənʌðɝ."

"The city is a box," Rand said. "The whole city and the area round it. They want me where they can control me, but they don't understand. Nobody controls me. Not anymore. I've had enough of boxes and prisons, of chains and ropes. Never again will I put myself into the power of another."

stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə sɪɾi, hi ɹitʃt tə ɪts pleɪs ɑn ɪz sæɾəl ən ɹimuv ðə stætʃuɛɾ ʌv ə mæn hoʊldɪŋ əlɔft ə ɡloʊb. nɪneɪiv fɛlt ə ʃɑɹp tʃɪl. dɪɾ i hæv tə bɹɪŋ ðət wɪð ɪm ɛvɹiwɛɹ i wɛnt?

Still staring at the city, he reached to its place on his saddle and removed the statuette of a man holding aloft a globe. Nynaeve felt a sharp chill. Did he have to bring that with him everywhere he went?

"pɝhæps ðeɪ nid tə bi tɔt," ɹænd sɛd. "ɡɪvən ɛnkɝɪdʒmən tə də ðɛɹ duɾi ən oʊbeɪ mi."

"Perhaps they need to be taught," Rand said. "Given encouragement to do their duty and obey me."

"ɹænd. . . ." nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk. ʃi kʊdn lɛt ðɪs hæpən əɡɛn!

"Rand. . . ." Nynaeve tried to think. She couldn't let this happen again!

ði æksɛs ki bɪɡæn tə ɡloʊ feɪnli. "ðeɪ wɑnə kæptʃɝ mi," hi sɛd sɔfli. "hoʊl mi. bit mi. ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪt wʌns ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi. ðeɪ - "

The access key began to glow faintly. "They want to capture me," he said softly. "Hold me. Beat me. They did it once in Far Madding already. They - "

"ɹænd!" nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɑɹpli.

"Rand!" Nynaeve said sharply.

hi stɑpt, lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, siɪŋ əɹ əz ɪf fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm.

He stopped, looking at her, seeing her as if for the first time.

"ðiz ɑɹ nɑt sleɪvz wɪð ðɛɹ maɪnz ɔlɹɛɾi bɝn əweɪ baɪ ɡɹeɪndəl. ðəɾ ɪz ən ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi fʊl ʌv ɪnəsən pipəl!"

"These are not slaves with their minds already burned away by Graendal. That is an entire city full of innocent people!"

"aɪ wʊdn hɑɹm ðə pipəl ə ðə sɪɾi," ɹænd sɛd, vɔɪs ɪmoʊʃənləs. "ðæɾ ɑɹmi dɪzɝvz ðə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən, nɑt ðə sɪɾi. ə ɹeɪn ə faɪɝ əpɑn ðɛm, pɝhæps. əɹ laɪtnɪŋ tə stʃɹaɪk ən baɪt."

"I wouldn't harm the people of the city," Rand said, voice emotionless. "That army deserves the demonstration, not the city. A rain of fire upon them, perhaps. Or lightning to strike and bite."

"ðeɪ hæv dʌn nʌθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən æsk jə tə mit wɪð ðɛm!" nɪneɪiv sɛd, ɛdʒɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs kloʊsɝ tə hɪm. ðət tɛɹæŋɡɹil sæt laɪk ə vaɪpɝ ɪn ɪz hænd. wʌns, ɪt hæd klɛnz ðə sɔɹs. ɪf oʊnli ɪt hæd mɛltəɾ əweɪ əz ðə fimeɪl wʌn hæd!

"They have done nothing other than ask you to meet with them!" Nynaeve said, edging her horse closer to him. That ter'angreal sat like a viper in his hand. Once, it had cleansed the Source. If only it had melted away as the female one had!

ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf i eɪmd ə wiv ɪndə ðə pɹətɛktɪv bʌbəl ə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, bʌt ʃi səspɛktəɾ ɪt wəd stɪl wɝk. ðə ɡɑɹɾiən dɪdn stɑp wivz fɹəm biɪŋ meɪd;

She wasn't certain what would happen if he aimed a weave into the protective bubble of Far Madding, but she suspected it would still work. The Guardian didn't stop weaves from being made;

nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə kɹæft wivz dʒʌs faɪn, wən ʃid dʒɹɔn əpɑn əɹ wɛl.

Nynaeve had been able to craft weaves just fine, when she'd drawn upon her Well.

iðɝ weɪ, ʃi nu ðət ʃi hæd tə stɑp ɹænd fɹəm tɝnɪŋ ɪz æŋɡɝ - əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz i fɛlt  - əpɑn ɪz ælaɪz. "ɹænd," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "ɪf jə də ðɪs, ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ tɝnɪŋ bæk."

Either way, she knew that she had to stop Rand from turning his anger - or whatever it was he felt  - upon his allies. "Rand," she said softly. "If you do this, there will be no turning back."

"ðɛɹz ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ tɝnɪŋ bæk fəɹ mi, nɪneɪiv," hi sɛd, hɪz aɪz ɪntɛns. ðoʊz aɪz ʃɪftəd, səmtaɪmz simɪŋ ɡɹeɪ, səmtaɪmz blu. tədeɪ, ðeɪ lʊkt aɪɝn ɡɹeɪ. hi kəntɪnjud, vɔɪs flæt.

"There's already no turning back for me, Nynaeve," he said, his eyes intense. Those eyes shifted, sometimes seeming gray, sometimes blue. Today, they looked iron gray. He continued, voice flat.

"maɪ fit stɑɹɾəd ɑn ðɪs pæθ ðə moʊmən tæm faʊn mi kɹaɪɪŋ ɑn ðət maʊntən."

"My feet started on this path the moment Tam found me crying on that mountain."

"ju doʊn əv tə kɪl ɛniwʌn tədeɪ. pliz."

"You don't have to kill anyone today. Please."

hi tɝn tə lʊk bæk ət ðə sɪɾi. sloʊli, mɝsɪfəli, ði æksɛs ki stɑpt ɡloʊɪŋ. "hʊɹɪn!"

He turned to look back at the city. Slowly, mercifully, the access key stopped glowing. "Hurin!"

hi bɑɹkt.

he barked.

hi mʌs bi kloʊs tə fɹeɪɪŋ, nɪneɪiv θɔt. hɪz æŋɡɝ ɪz slɪpɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs.

He must be close to fraying, Nynaeve thought. His anger is slipping out in his voice.

ðə θif-teɪkɝ ɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ðə fɹʌn ə ðə ɡɹup. ði il kɛp ðɛɹ dɪstəns, haʊɛvɝ. "jɛs, lɔɹd ɹænd?"

The thief-taker rode up to the front of the group. The Aiel kept their distance, however. "Yes, Lord Rand?"

"ɹɪtɝn tə jəɹ mæstɝz ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðɛɹ bɑks," ɹænd sɛd, vɔɪs ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl əɡɛn. "ju ɑɹ tə ɡɪv əm ə mɛsədʒ fəɹ mi."

"Return to your masters inside of their box," Rand said, voice under control again. "You are to give them a message for me."

"wʌt mɛsədʒ, lɔɹd ɹænd?"

"What message, Lord Rand?"

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən slɪp ði æksɛs ki bæk ɪn ɪts pleɪs. "tɛl əm ðəɾ ɪɾəl nɑt bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɹaɪdz tə bæɾəl ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ɪf ðeɪ wɪʃ tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ poʊsts wɪð ɑnɝ, əl pɹəvaɪɾ əm wɪð tʃɹænspɔɹt bæk tə ðə blaɪt. ʌðɝwaɪz, ðeɪ kən ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ, haɪɾɪŋ.

Rand hesitated, then slipped the access key back in its place. "Tell them that it will not be long before the Dragon Reborn rides to battle at Shayol Ghul. If they wish to return to their posts with honor, I will provide them with transport back to the Blight. Otherwise, they can remain here, hiding.

lɛɾ əm ɪkspleɪn tə ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən ən ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹən waɪ ðeɪ wɝ hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz əweɪ fɹəm ðɛɹ poʊsts wən ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz sleɪn ən ðə pɹɑfəsiz fʊlfɪld."

Let them explain to their children and grandchildren why they were hundreds of leagues away from their posts when the Dark One was slain and the prophecies fulfilled."

hʊɹɪn lʊkt ʃeɪkən. "jɛs, lɔɹd ɹænd."

Hurin looked shaken. "Yes, Lord Rand."

wɪð ðæt, ɹænd tɝn ɪz hɔɹs əbaʊɾ ən ɹoʊd bæk təwɔɹd ðə klɪɹɪŋ. nɪneɪiv fɑloʊd, tu sloʊli. bjuɾəfəl ðoʊ munlaɪt wɑz, ʃiɾ əv tʃɹeɪɾɪd ðə bjuɾəfəl mɛɹ ɪn ən ɪnstən fəɹ ə bɪɾəbəl, dɪpɛndəbəl tu ɹɪvɝz hɔɹs laɪk bɛlə.

With that, Rand turned his horse about and rode back toward the clearing. Nynaeve followed, too slowly. Beautiful though Moonlight was, she'd have traded the beautiful mare in an instant for a biddable, dependable Two Rivers horse like Bela.

hʊɹɪn steɪd bɪhaɪnd. hi stɪl lʊkt ʃeɪkən. hɪz ɹiunjən wɪð "lɔɹd ɹænd" hæɾ ɑbviəsli bɪn fɑɹ fɹəm wʌɾ i ɪkspɛktəd. nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ əz ðə tʃɹiz əbskjʊɹɾ əɹ vju ʌv hɪm. ɪnsaɪd ðə klɪɹɪŋ, ɹænd hæɾ oʊpən ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ, ə dɝɛkt ɡeɪtweɪ tə tɛɹ.

Hurin stayed behind. He still looked shaken. His reunion with "Lord Rand" had obviously been far from what he expected. Nynaeve gritted her teeth as the trees obscured her view of him. Inside the clearing, Rand had opened another gateway, a direct gateway to Tear.

ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊn pɹipɛɹɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹz steɪbliɑɹdz. ði ɛɹ wɑz hɑɾ ən mʌɡi ɪn tɛɹ, dɪspaɪt ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ, ən θɪk wɪð ðə saʊnz ə mɛn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ən ɡʌlz ʃɹikɪŋ. ɹænd ɹoʊɾ aʊt tə wɛɹ steɪbəlɪhənz weɪɾəd, ðən dɪsmaʊntɪd, hɪz feɪs ənɹiɾəbəl.

They rode out into the Traveling ground prepared outside the Stone of Tear's stableyards. The air was hot and muggy in Tear, despite the overcast sky, and thick with the sounds of men training and gulls shrieking. Rand rode out to where stablehands waited, then dismounted, his face unreadable.

əz nɪneɪiv klaɪmd ɔf ə munlaɪɾ ən hændəd ðə ɹeɪnz tə ə ɹʌɾi-feɪst steɪbəl wɝkɝ, ɹænd wɔk pæs hɝ. "lʊk fəɹ ə stætʃu," hi sɛd.

As Nynaeve climbed off of Moonlight and handed the reins to a ruddy-faced stable worker, Rand walked past her. "Look for a statue," he said.

"wʌt?" ʃi æskt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz.

"What?" she asked with surprise.

hi ɡlæns bæk ət hɝ, stɑpɪŋ. "ju æskt wɛɹ pɛɹɪn wɑz. hiz kæmpt wɪð ən ɑɹmi bɪniθ ðə ʃeɪɾ ʌv ən ɪnɔɹməs fɔlən stætʃu ʃeɪp laɪk ə sɔɹd stæbɪŋ ði ɝθ. aɪm sɝɾən skɑlɝz hɪɹ kən tɛl jə wɛɹ ɪɾ ɪz; ɪts vɛɹi dɪstɪŋktɪv."

He glanced back at her, stopping. "You asked where Perrin was. He's camped with an army beneath the shade of an enormous fallen statue shaped like a sword stabbing the earth. I'm certain scholars here can tell you where it is; it's very distinctive."

"haʊ . . . haʊ dʒju noʊ ðæt?"

"How . . . how do you know that?"

ɹænd dʒʌst ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ dʒʌs du."

Rand just shrugged. "I just do."

"waɪ tɛl mi?" ʃi æskt, wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪm əkɹɔs ðə jɑɹɾ ə pækt ɝθ. ʃi hædn ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə ɡɪv ʌp ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən - hi hæd ɡɑɾən ɪndə ðə hæbəɾ ə hoʊldɪŋ ɑntu wʌtɛvɝ i nu, ivən ɪf ðət nɑlədʒ wɑz minɪŋləs.

"Why tell me?" she asked, walking alongside him across the yard of packed earth. She hadn't expected him to give up the information - he had gotten into the habit of holding onto whatever he knew, even if that knowledge was meaningless.

"bɪkɔz," hi sɛd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kip, vɔɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tu sɑf tə hɪɹ, "aɪ . . . hæv ə dɛt tə jə fəɹ kɛɹɪŋ wən aɪ kænɑt. ɪf jə sik pɛɹɪn aʊt, tɛl ɪm ðəɾ əl sun nid hɪm."

"Because," he said, striding toward the keep, voice growing almost too soft to hear, "I . . . have a debt to you for caring when I cannot. If you seek Perrin out, tell him that I will soon need him."

wɪð ðæt, hi lɛf hɝ.

With that, he left her.

nɪneɪiv stʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔɹs jɑɹd, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɡoʊ. ðəɹ wɑz ə wɛt sɛn tə ði ɛɹ, ðə smɛl ə nu ɹeɪn, ən ʃi kəd fil ðət ʃid mɪst ə spɹɪŋkəl. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə klɪɹ ði ɛɹ əɹ mʌɾi ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌɾ ɪnʌf tə liv wɛɾɪd sɛkʃənz ə stoʊn ɪn ʃeɪɾɪd kɔɹnɝz. tə hɝ ɹaɪt, mɛn ɡæləpt ən ɛksɝsaɪz hɔɹsəz bɪniθ ðə dʌn skaɪ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs sændi ɝθ bɪtwin pɪkəts. ðə stoʊn wɑz ði oʊnli fɔɹtʃɹəs ʃi nu ʌv wɪð ɛksɝsaɪz ɛɹiəz fəɹ kævəlɹi - bʌt, ðɛn, ðə stoʊn wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ɔɹɾənɛɹi.

Nynaeve stood in the horse yard, watching him go. There was a wet scent to the air, the smell of new rain, and she could feel that she'd missed a sprinkle. Not enough to clear the air or muddy the ground, but enough to leave wetted sections of stone in shaded corners. To her right, men galloped and exercised horses beneath the dun sky, riding across sandy earth between pickets. The Stone was the only fortress she knew of with exercise areas for cavalry - but, then, the Stone was far from ordinary.

ðə ɹʌmbəl ə hʊfbits wɑz laɪk ðə saʊn ʌv ə dɪstən stɔɹm, ən ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf ɡlænsɪŋ nɔɹθwɝd. ðə stɔɹm ðəɹ fɛl kloʊsɝ ðən ɪt hæd bɪfɔɹ. ʃiɾ əsumd ɪt wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪn ðə blaɪt, bʌt naʊ ʃi wɑzn soʊ sɝɾən.

The rumble of hoofbeats was like the sound of a distant storm, and she found herself glancing northward. The storm there felt closer than it had before. She'd assumed it was gathering in the Blight, but now she wasn't so certain.

ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən heɪsən tə ðə kip. ʃi pæs dɪfɛndɝz ɪn ðɛɹ ɪmækjulɪt junəfɔɹmz, ði ʌpɝ ɑɹm pɔɹʃənz ɹɪbd ən pʌfi, bɹɛstpleɪts smuð ən kɝvd. ʃi pæst steɪbəlbɔɪz, itʃ pɹɑbli dʒɹimɪŋ ʌv wʌn deɪ wɛɹɪŋ ðət seɪm junəfɔɹm, bʌt fəɹ naʊ oʊnli liɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz bæk tə ðə steɪbəlz fəɹ heɪ ən kʌɝiɪŋ. ʃi pæs dʌzənz ə sɝvəns ɪn lɪnənz, daʊtləs fɑɹ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl ðən nɪneɪivz mɝun wʊl.

She took a deep breath, then hastened to the keep. She passed Defenders in their immaculate uniforms, the upper arm portions ribbed and puffy, breastplates smooth and curved. She passed stableboys, each probably dreaming of one day wearing that same uniform, but for now only leading horses back to the stables for hay and currying. She passed dozens of servants in linens, doubtless far more comfortable than Nynaeve's maroon wool.

ðə kip ɪtsɛlf wɑz ə taʊɝɪŋ ɹɑk ʌv ə stʃɹʌktʃɝ, ʃɪɹ wɔlz bɹoʊkən oʊnli baɪ wɪndoʊz. ɪksɛp ðət ʃi kəd stɪl spɑt ðə pleɪs wɛɹ mæt hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ə sɛkʃən ə stoʊn wɪð ɪz ɪluməneɪɾɝz faɪɹwɝks wən kʌmɪŋ tə ɹɛskju nɪneɪiv ən ði ʌðɝz fɹəm ðɛɹ ɪmpɹɪzənmənt. ful bɔɪ. wɛɹ wɑz hi? ʃi hædn sin ɪm ɪn . . . ɪn kwaɪɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm. sɪns ɛbu dɑɹ hæd fɔlən tə ðə sintʃæn. ɪn ə weɪ, ʃi fɛlt əz ðoʊ ʃiɾ əbændən hɪm, ðoʊ ʃid nɛvɝ ədmɪt ðæt. waɪ, ʃiɾ ɪmbɛɹəs hɝsɛlf ɪnʌf ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz wən ʃid dɪfɛndəd ðət skaʊnʒɹəl! ʃi stɪl dɪdnt noʊ wʌt hæd kʌm oʊvɝ hɝ.

The keep itself was a towering rock of a structure, sheer walls broken only by windows. Except that she could still spot the place where Mat had destroyed a section of stone with his Illuminator's fireworks when coming to rescue Nynaeve and the others from their imprisonment. Fool boy. Where was he? She hadn't seen him in . . . in quite a long time. Since Ebou Dar had fallen to the Seanchan. In a way, she felt as though she'd abandoned him, though she'd never admit that. Why, she'd embarrassed herself enough in front of the Daughter of the Nine Moons when she'd defended that scoundrel! She still didn't know what had come over her.

mæt kəd kɛɹ fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. hi wɑz pɹɑbli kəɹaʊzəŋ ɪn səm ɪn waɪl ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm wɝk tə seɪv ðə wɝld - dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf sɪli ən pleɪɪŋ ət daɪs. ɹænd wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. hid bɪn soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ tə dil wɪð wən hid kəntɪnjud tə æk laɪk ʌðɝ mɛn - stʌbɝn ən ɪmətʃjʊɹ, bʌt pɹɪdɪktəbəl. ðɪs nu ɹænd wɪð ðə koʊld ɪmoʊʃənz ən ðə koʊl vɔɪs wɑz tʃɹuli ənɝvɪŋ.

Mat could care for himself. He was probably carousing in some inn while the rest of them worked to save the world - drinking himself silly and playing at dice. Rand was another matter. He'd been so much easier to deal with when he'd continued to act like other men - stubborn and immature, but predictable. This new Rand with the cold emotions and the cold voice was truly unnerving.

ðə nɛɹoʊ kɔɹɪɾɝz ə ðə stoʊn wɝ stɪl ʌnfəmɪljɝ tə nɪneɪiv, ən ʃi ɔfən ɡɑt lɔst. hɝ dɪsɔɹiənteɪʃən wɑzn hɛlp baɪ ðə fæk ðət hɔlweɪz ən wɔlz səmtaɪmz tʃeɪnʒd pleɪsəz. ʃid tʃɹaɪd tə dɪskaʊn sətʃ teɪlz əz supɝstɪʃəs nɑnsɛns, bʌt ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, ʃid woʊkən tə dɪskʌvɝ ðəɾ əɹ ɹum hæɾ ɪndid sʌɾənli ən mɪstɪɹiəsli muvd. hɝ dɔɹ hæɾ oʊpən tə ə smuð wɔl ə ðə seɪm simləs ɹɑk əz ðə stoʊn ɪtsɛlf. ʃid bɪn fɔɹs tə ɪskeɪp θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən hæd bɪn ʃɑk tə lɝn ðəɾ əɹ wɪndoʊ lʊkt aʊt fɹəm ə loʊkeɪʃən tu stɔɹiz haɪɝ ðən ɪt hæd ðə pɹiviəs naɪt!

The narrow corridors of the Stone were still unfamiliar to Nynaeve, and she often got lost. Her disorientation wasn't helped by the fact that hallways and walls sometimes changed places. She'd tried to discount such tales as superstitious nonsense, but the day before, she'd woken to discover that her room had indeed suddenly and mysteriously moved. Her door had opened to a smooth wall of the same seamless rock as the Stone itself. She'd been forced to escape through a gateway, and had been shocked to learn that her window looked out from a location two stories higher than it had the previous night!

kædzueɪn sɛɾ ɪt wɑz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ ɑn ðə wɝld, kɑzɪŋ ðə pæɾɝn tə ənɹævəl. kædzueɪn sɛɾ ə lɑɾ ə θɪŋz, ən fju ʌv əm wɝ θɪŋz ðət nɪneɪiv wɪʃt tə hɪɹ.

Cadsuane said it was the Dark One's touch on the world, causing the Pattern to unravel. Cadsuane said a lot of things, and few of them were things that Nynaeve wished to hear.

nɪneɪiv ɡɑt lɔs twaɪs əz ʃi woʊv əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz, bʌt ʃi ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɝaɪvd ət kædzueɪnz ɹum. ət list ɹænd hædn fɔɹbɪɾən ɪz stuɝdz tə ɡɹæn əɹ ɹumz. nɪneɪiv nɑkt  - ʃid lɝn ðət ʃid bɛɾɝ - ðən ɛntɝd.

Nynaeve got lost twice as she wove her way through the corridors, but she eventually arrived at Cadsuane's room. At least Rand hadn't forbidden his stewards to grant her rooms. Nynaeve knocked  - she'd learned that she'd better - then entered.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm kædzueɪnz ɡɹup - mɛɹaɪs ən kɔɹəl - sæɾ ɪn ðə ɹum, nɪɾɪŋ ən sɪpɪŋ ti, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk laɪk ðeɪ wɝ nɑt weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ɪnfɝnəl wʊmənz wɪmz. kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf wɑz spikɪŋ kwaɪətli wɪð mɪn, hum ʃi hæɾ ɔl bʌɾ əpɹoʊpɹieɪɾɪd ɪn ɹisən deɪz. mɪn hɝsɛlf dɪdn sim tə maɪnd, pɝhæps kəz ɪt wɑzn izi tə spɛn taɪm wɪð ɹænd ðiz deɪz. nɪneɪiv fɛlt ə stæb ə sɪmpəθi fəɹ ðə ɡɝl. nɪneɪiv oʊnli hæd tə dil wɪð ɹænd əz ə fɹɛnd; ɔl ə ðɪs wəd bi mʌtʃ hɑɹʃɝ ɑn ðə wʌn u ʃɛɹɾ ɪz hɑɹt.

The Aes Sedai from Cadsuane's group - Merise and Corele - sat in the room, knitting and sipping tea, trying to look like they were not waiting on the infernal woman's whims. Cadsuane herself was speaking quietly with Min, whom she had all but appropriated in recent days. Min herself didn't seem to mind, perhaps because it wasn't easy to spend time with Rand these days. Nynaeve felt a stab of sympathy for the girl. Nynaeve only had to deal with Rand as a friend; all of this would be much harsher on the one who shared his heart.

ɔl aɪz tɝn təwɔɹd nɪneɪiv əz ʃi kloʊz ðə dɔɹ. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪv faʊn hɪm," ʃi ənaʊnst.

All eyes turned toward Nynaeve as she closed the door. "I think I've found him," she announced.

"hu ɪz ðæt, tʃaɪld?" kædzueɪn sɛd, lifɪŋ θɹu wʌn ə mɪnz bʊks.

"Who is that, child?" Cadsuane said, leafing through one of Min's books.

"pɛɹɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ju wɝ ɹaɪt; ɹænd dɪd noʊ wɛɹ i wɑz."

"Perrin," Nynaeve said. "You were right; Rand did know where he was."

"ɛksələnt!" kædzueɪn sɛd. "ju dɪd wɛl; ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðət jə kən bi ʌv jus."

"Excellent!" Cadsuane said. "You did well; it appears that you can be of use."

nɪneɪiv wɑzn sɝɾən wɪtʃ ənɔɪɾ əɹ mɔɹ - ðə bækhændəd kɑmpləmənt, əɹ ðə fæk ðəɾ əɹ hɑɹt swɛld wɪð pɹaɪɾ ət hɪɹɪŋ ɪt. ʃi wɑz noʊ ɡɝl, wɪθaʊɾ əɹ bɹeɪd, tə bi stʃɹoʊk baɪ ðɪs wʊmənz wɝdz!

Nynaeve wasn't certain which annoyed her more - the backhanded compliment, or the fact that her heart swelled with pride at hearing it. She was no girl, without her braid, to be stroked by this woman's words!

"wɛl?" kædzueɪn lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə bʊk. ði ʌðɝz ɹɪmeɪn saɪlənt, ðoʊ mɪn dɪd ʃut nɪneɪiv ə kənɡɹætʃələtɔɹi smaɪl. "wɛɹ ɪz hi?"

"Well?" Cadsuane looked up from the book. The others remained silent, though Min did shoot Nynaeve a congratulatory smile. "Where is he?"

nɪneɪivz oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə ɹɪplaɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kɑt hɝsɛlf. wʌt wɑz ɪɾ əbaʊt ðɪs wʊmən ðət meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə oʊbeɪ? ɪt wɑzn ðə wʌn paʊɝ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪt. kædzueɪn sɪmpli pɹədʒɛktəd ði ɛɹ ʌv ə stɝn, bʌt fɛɹ, ɡɹændmʌðɝ. ðə taɪp jə nɛvɝ spoʊk bæk tə, bʌɾ u wəd ɡɪv jə səm beɪk swits ɪn ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ swipɪŋ ðə flɔɹ wən toʊld.

Nynaeve's opened her mouth to reply before she caught herself. What was it about this woman that made her want to obey? It wasn't the One Power or anything to do with it. Cadsuane simply projected the air of a stern, but fair, grandmother. The type you never spoke back to, but who would give you some baked sweets in reward for sweeping the floor when told.

"fɝst, aɪ wɑnə noʊ waɪ pɛɹɪn ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt." nɪneɪiv stɔkt ɪndə ðə ɹum ən tʊk ði oʊnli ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ sit, ə peɪntəd wʊɾən stul. wən ʃi sæt, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf sɪɾɪŋ ə fju ɪntʃəz bɪloʊ aɪ lɛvəl. laɪk ə stuɾənt bɪfɔɹ kædzueɪn. ʃi ɔlmoʊst stʊɾ ʌp, bʌt ɹilaɪz ðət wəd dʒɹɔ mɔɹ ətɛnʃən.

"First, I want to know why Perrin is important." Nynaeve stalked into the room and took the only remaining seat, a painted wooden stool. When she sat, she found herself sitting a few inches below eye level. Like a student before Cadsuane. She almost stood up, but realized that would draw more attention.

"fɔ!" kædzueɪn sɛd. "jud hoʊl ðɪs nɑlədʒ bæk, ivən ɪf ɪt minz ðə laɪvz ə ðoʊz jə hoʊl dɪɹ?"

"Phaw!" Cadsuane said. "You'd hold this knowledge back, even if it means the lives of those you hold dear?"

"aɪ wɑnə noʊ wʌɾ aɪv ɡɑɾən maɪsɛlf ɪntu," nɪneɪiv sɛd stʌbɝnli. "aɪ wɑnə noʊ ðət ðɪs ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɪzən gɑnə ɛn ʌp hɝɾɪŋ ɹænd fɝðɝ."

"I want to know what I've gotten myself into," Nynaeve said stubbornly. "I want to know that this information isn't going to end up hurting Rand further."

kædzueɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "ju pɹɪzum tə θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪd hɝt ðə ful bɔɪ?"

Cadsuane snorted. "You presume to think that I'd hurt the fool boy?"

"aɪm nɑt gɑnə pɹɪzum ʌðɝwaɪz," nɪneɪiv snæpt. "nɑɾ əntɪl jə tɛl mi wʌt jə ɑɹ duɪŋ."

"I'm not going to presume otherwise," Nynaeve snapped. "Not until you tell me what you are doing."

kædzueɪn kloʊz ðə bʊk -  ɛkoʊz ə hɪz daɪnəsti - ən lʊk pɝtɝbd. "wɪl jə ət lis tɛl mi haʊ ðə miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɛnt?" ʃi æskt. "ɔɹ ɪz ðəɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən hɛl fəɹ ɹænsəm əz wɛl?"

Cadsuane closed the book -  Echoes of His Dynasty - and looked perturbed. "Will you at least tell me how the meeting with the Borderlanders went?" she asked. "Or is that information held for ransom as well?"

dɪd ʃi θɪŋk ʃid dɪstʃɹæk nɪneɪiv ðəɾ izəli? "ɪt wɛn pʊɹli, əz wʌn maɪɾ ɪkspɛkt," ʃi sɛd.

Did she think she'd distract Nynaeve that easily? "It went poorly, as one might expect," she said.

"ðeɪv hʌŋkɝd daʊn aʊtsaɪd fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ən ɹəfjuz tə mit wɪð ɹænd ənlɛs i kʌmz wɪðɪn ɹeɪnʒ ə ðə ɡɑɹɾiən, kʌɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɔf fɹəm ðə sɔɹs."

"They've hunkered down outside Far Madding and refuse to meet with Rand unless he comes within range of the Guardian, cutting himself off from the Source."

"dɪɾ i teɪk ɪt wɛl?" kɔɹəl æsk fɹəm əɹ kʊʃən bɛntʃ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum. ʃi smaɪl feɪnli; ʃi sim tə bi ði oʊnli wʌn u θɔt ðə tʃeɪnʒəz ɪn ɹænd wɝ əmjuzɪŋ, ɹæðɝ ðən tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ. bʌt, ðɛn, ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə wɪmən u hæd bɑndəɾ ən æʃəmən ət pɹæktəkli ðə fɝst ɑpɝtunəɾi.

"Did he take it well?" Corele asked from her cushioned bench at the side of the room. She smiled faintly; she seemed to be the only one who thought the changes in Rand were amusing, rather than terrifying. But, then, she was one of the women who had bonded an Asha'man at practically the first opportunity.

"dɪɾ i teɪk ɪt wɛl?" nɪneɪiv ɹɪpiɾɪd flætli. "ðæt dɪpɛnz. dʌz pʊlɪŋ aʊt ðət blæstəd tɛɹæŋɡɹil ən θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə ɹeɪn daʊn faɪɝ ɑn ði ɑɹmi stʃɹaɪk jə əz 'teɪkɪŋ ɪt wɛl'?"

"Did he take it well?" Nynaeve repeated flatly. "That depends. Does pulling out that blasted ter'angreal and threatening to rain down fire on the army strike you as 'Taking it well'?"

mɪn peɪld. kædzueɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ.

Min paled. Cadsuane raised an eyebrow.

"aɪ stɑp hɪm," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "bʌt dʒʌs bɛɹli. aɪ doʊnt noʊ. ɪt . . . ɪt maɪt bi ɡɛɾɪŋ tu leɪt tə də ɛniθɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ hɪm."

"I stopped him," Nynaeve said. "But just barely. I don't know. It . . . it might be getting too late to do anything to change him."

"ðæt bɔɪ wɪl læf əɡɛn," kædzueɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, bʌɾ ɪntɛnsli. "aɪ dɪdn lɪv ðɪs lɔŋ tə feɪl naʊ."

"That boy will laugh again," Cadsuane said quietly, but intensely. "I didn't live this long to fail now."

"wʌt dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ?" kɔɹəl sɛd.

"What does it matter?" Corele said.

nɪneɪiv tɝn ɪn ʃɑk.

Nynaeve turned in shock.

"wɛl?" kɔɹəl sɛt daʊn əɹ mɛndɪŋ. "wʌt dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ? wɝ ɑbviəsli ɡoʊɪŋ tə səksid."

"Well?" Corele set down her mending. "What does it matter? We're obviously going to succeed."

"laɪt!" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "wʌt ɡeɪv jə ðəɾ aɪdiə?"

"Light!" Nynaeve said. "What gave you that idea?"

"wiv dʒʌst spɛn ɔl æftɝnun dʒɹɪlɪŋ ðɪs ɡɝl əbaʊɾ əɹ vɪʒənz." kɔɹəl nɑɾəd tə mɪn. "ðeɪ ɔlweɪz kʌm tʃɹu, ən ʃiz sin θɪŋz ðəɾ ɑbviəsli kæn hæpən əntɪl æftɝ ðə læs bæɾəl. soʊ wi noʊ ðət ɹænd ɪz gɑnə dɪfit ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðə pæɾɝn əz ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt. wi kən stɑp wɝiɪŋ."

"We've just spent all afternoon drilling this girl about her visions." Corele nodded to Min. "They always come true, and she's seen things that obviously can't happen until after the Last Battle. So we know that Rand is going to defeat the Dark One. The Pattern has already decided it. We can stop worrying."

"noʊ," mɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ ɹɔŋ."

"No," Min said. "You're wrong."

kɔɹəl fɹaʊnd. "tʃaɪld, ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ ðət jə laɪɾ əbaʊt ðə θɪŋz juv sin?"

Corele frowned. "Child, are you saying that you lied about the things you've seen?"

"noʊ," mɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪf ɹænd luzəz, ðəɹ ɪz noʊ pæɾɝn."

"No," Min said. "But if Rand loses, there is no Pattern."

"ðə ɡɝl ɪz kɝɛkt." kædzueɪn saʊndəd sɝpɹaɪzd. "wʌt ðɪs tʃaɪl siz ɑɹ wivɪŋz ɪn ðə pæɾɝn fɹəm ə taɪm stɪl dɪstənt - bʌɾ ɪf ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪnz, hɪl dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə pæɾɝn ɪntaɪɝli. ðɪs ɪz ði oʊnli weɪ ðə vɪʒənz kəd feɪl tə əkɝ. ðə seɪm hoʊlz fəɹ ʌðɝ pɹɑfəsiz ən fɔɹtɛlɪŋz.

"The girl is correct." Cadsuane sounded surprised. "What this child sees are weavings in the Pattern from a time still distant - but if the Dark One wins, he will destroy the Pattern entirely. This is the only way the visions could fail to occur. The same holds for other prophecies and Foretellings.

əɹ vɪktɝi ɪz baɪ noʊ minz ʃʊɹ."

Our victory is by no means sure."

ðət stɪl ðə ɹum. ðeɪ wɝn pleɪɪŋ ət vɪlədʒ pɑlətɪks əɹ næʃənəl dɑmənəns. ət steɪk wɑz kɹieɪʃən ɪtsɛlf.

That stilled the room. They weren't playing at village politics or national dominance. At stake was creation itself.

laɪt. kən aɪ wɪθhoʊl ðɪs ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɪf ðɛɹz ɛni tʃæns ʌv ɪt hɛlpɪŋ læn? ɪt ɹɛntʃt əɹ hɑɹt tə θɪŋk ə hɪm, ən ʃi hæd fju ɑpʃənz. ɪn fækt, lænz oʊnli hoʊp sim tə ɹɛst ɪn ði ɑɹmiz ɹænd kəd mɑɹʃəl ən ðə ɡeɪtweɪz ɪz pipəl kəd fɔɹm.

Light. Can I withhold this information if there's any chance of it helping Lan? It wrenched her heart to think of him, and she had few options. In fact, Lan's only hope seemed to rest in the armies Rand could marshal and the gateways his people could form.

ɹænd hæd tə tʃeɪnʒ. fəɹ læn. fəɹ əm ɔl. ən ʃi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌt tə də ʌðɝ ðæn, ənfɔɹtʃənətli, tə tʃɹʌs kædzueɪn. nɪneɪiv swɑloʊɾ əɹ pɹaɪɾ ən spoʊk. "du jə noʊ ðə loʊkeɪʃən ʌv ə stætʃu ʌv ən ɪnɔɹməs sɔɹd, fɔlən tə ði ɝθ əz ɪf stæbɪŋ ɪt?"

Rand had to change. For Lan. For them all. And she had no idea what to do other than, unfortunately, to trust Cadsuane. Nynaeve swallowed her pride and spoke. "Do you know the location of a statue of an enormous sword, fallen to the earth as if stabbing it?"

kɔɹəl ən mɛɹaɪs ɡlænst əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ɪn kənfjuʒən.

Corele and Merise glanced at each other in confusion.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾifaɪv

ðə taʊɝ stænz ɛɡwin wɔk sloʊli θɹu ðə ɹɛbəl kæmp, wɛɹɪŋ ə kɹɪmzən ɡaʊn, ɪts skɝts dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ. ðə kʌlɝ ɹeɪz nɑɾ ə fju aɪbɹaʊz. kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wʌt ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ hæd dʌn, ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝn laɪkli tə wɛɹ ðə hju. ivən ðə kæmps sɝvɪŋ wɪmən hæd noʊɾəst, sɛlɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹɛɾ ən mɝun dʒɹɛsəz əɹ kʌɾɪŋ əm ʌp fəɹ ɹæɡz.

The Tower Stands Egwene walked slowly through the rebel camp, wearing a crimson gown, its skirts divided for riding. The color raised not a few eyebrows. Considering what the Red Ajah had done, these Aes Sedai weren't likely to wear the hue. Even the camp's serving women had noticed, selling their red and maroon dresses or cutting them up for rags.

ɛɡwin hæɾ æsk fəɹ ðə kɹɪmzən spəsɪfɪkli. ɪn ðə taʊɝ, sɪstɝz hæd fɔɹm ðə hæbəɾ ʌv wɛɹɪŋ oʊnli ðɛɹ oʊn ədʒɑz kʌlɝ, ən ðə pɹæktəs hæd hɛlp fjuəl ðə dɪvɪʒən. waɪl ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə bi pɹaʊɾ ə jəɹ ədʒɑ əfɪlieɪʃən, ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs tə bɪɡɪn əsumɪŋ ðət jə kʊdn tʃɹʌst ɛniwʌn wɛɹɪŋ ʌðɝ kʌlɝz.

Egwene had asked for the crimson specifically. In the Tower, sisters had formed the habit of wearing only their own Ajah's color, and the practice had helped fuel the division. While it was good to be proud of your Ajah affiliation, it was dangerous to begin assuming that you couldn't trust anyone wearing other colors.

ɛɡwin wɑz ɔl ədʒəz. tədeɪ, ðə ɹɛd sɪmbəlaɪz mɛni θɪŋz tə hɝ. ði ɪmpɛndɪŋ ɹiunəfəkeɪʃən wɪð ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. ə ɹimaɪndɝ ə ðə dɪvɪʒən ðət niɾəd tə bi ɹaɪɾɪd. ə saɪn ə ðə blʌd ðət wəd bi spɪld, ðə blʌɾ ʌv ɡʊd mɛn u fɔt tə dɪfɛn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Egwene was all Ajahs. Today, the red symbolized many things to her. The impending reunification with the Red Ajah. A reminder of the division that needed to be righted. A sign of the blood that would be spilled, the blood of good men who fought to defend the White Tower.

ðə blʌɾ ə ðə dɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bɪhɛɾɪd nɑɾ ən aʊɝ əɡoʊ baɪ ɛɡwinz ɔɹɾɝ.

The blood of the dead Aes Sedai, beheaded not an hour ago by Egwene's order.

sɪuən hæd faʊn əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ; ɪt fɛl vɛɹi ɡʊd tə hæv ɪɾ ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝ əɡɛn.

Siuan had found her Great Serpent ring; it felt very good to have it on her finger again.

ðə skaɪ wɑz ən aɪɝn ɡɹeɪ, ən ðə sɛn ə dɝt ɹoʊz ɪndə ði ɛɹ, əkʌmpəniɪŋ ðə bʌsəlɪŋ moʊʃən ɝaʊn ðə kæmp. wɪmən hɝidli wɑʃt kloʊðɪŋ, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ leɪɾ ɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ peɪtʃɹənz ɹɛɾi fəɹ ə fɛstəvəl. nɑvəsɪz ɹæn - lɪɾɝəli ɹæn - fɹəm lɛsən tə lɛsən. ɛɛs sədaɪ stʊɾ əbaʊt wɪð ɑɹmz foʊldəd, aɪz ɹɛɾi tə bɝn ɛni hu dɪdn kip ʌp ðə tɛmpoʊ.

The sky was an iron gray, and the scent of dirt rose into the air, accompanying the bustling motion around the camp. Women hurriedly washed clothing, as if they were late in getting their patrons ready for a festival. Novices ran - literally ran - from lesson to lesson. Aes Sedai stood about with arms folded, eyes ready to burn any who didn't keep up the tempo.

The night before, with its attack by the Seanchan. Followed by the return of the Amyrlin, who had spent the morning cleansing the Aes Sedai. And now afternoon, and the beating drums of war.

ʃi daʊɾɪd ðət bɹaɪnz oʊn kæmp wɑz ɪn sətʃ ə steɪt. hiɾ əv ɪz mɛn ɹɛɾi fəɹ ətæk; hi pɹɑbli cʊɾə əsɔltɪd ðə waɪt taʊɝ əɾ ə moʊməns noʊɾəs ɑn ɛni ɡɪvən deɪ ʌv ðə sidʒ.

She doubted that Bryne's own camp was in such a state. He'd have his men ready for attack; he probably could have assaulted the White Tower at a moment's notice on any given day of the siege.

His soldiers would decide this war. Egwene would not have her Aes Sedai riding into battle, wriggling around their oaths not to use the Power to kill. They would wait here, to be called only for Healing.

They'd placed her head on the block and taken it off, just like the others. Some of the Sitters had argued for interrogation instead of execution, but Egwene had been insistent. Fifty women were far too many to shield and guard, and now that they knew stilling could be Healed, that wasn't an option. No, history proved how slippery and dangerous members of the Black could be, and Egwene was tired of worrying about what could happen. She had learned with Moghedien that there was a price to be paid for greed, if just greed for information. She and the others had been too eager - too proud of the "discoveries" they'd made - to see the world rid of one of the Forsaken.

You did well, Verin. So very well. Every Aes Sedai in the camp had been made to swear the Three Oaths over again, and only three members of the Black had been discovered beyond the ones Verin had located. Her research had been thorough.

The Blacks' Warders were under guard. They would have to be sorted through at a later date, when attention could be given to separating those who were really Black from those who were just enraged by the loss of their Aes Sedai. Most of them would seek death, even the innocent ones.

Perhaps the innocent could be convinced to remain alive long enough to throw themselves into the Last Battle.

nɪɹli twɛnti ʌv ðə blæk sɪstɝz ɑn vɛɹɪnz lɪs hæd stɪl ɪskeɪpt, dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ʌv ɛɡwinz pɹikɔʃənz. ʃi wɑzn sɝɾən haʊ ðeɪ hæd noʊn. bɹaɪnz ɡɑɹdz hæd kɑt səm wikɝ wʌnz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fli, ən soʊlʒɝz hæd fɔlən tə dɪleɪ ðɛm. bʌt mɛni hæd stɪl ɪskeɪpt.

Nearly twenty of the Black sisters on Verin's list had still escaped, despite all of Egwene's precautions. She wasn't certain how they had known. Bryne's guards had caught some weaker ones trying to flee, and soldiers had fallen to delay them. But many had still escaped.

noʊ jus kɹaɪɪŋ oʊvɝ ðæt. fɪfti blæk wɝ dɛd; ðət wɑz ə vɪktɝi. ə fɹaɪɾənɪŋ wʌn. bʌɾ ə vɪktɝi nʌnðəlɛs.

No use crying over that. Fifty Black were dead; that was a victory. A frightening one. But a victory nonetheless.

And so she walked through the camp, in riding boots and a dress of red, brown hair free to stream in the wind and tied with crimson ribbons to mark the streams of blood she had shed not an hour before. She did not blame the sisters around her for their sly glances, their masked concern, their fear.

ən ðɛɹ ɹɪspɛkt. ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɛni daʊt ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz æmɪɝlɪn, ɪt hæd bɪn dɪspɛld. ðeɪ æksɛptɪd hɝ, ðeɪ fɪɹd hɝ. ən ʃi wəd nɛvɝ kwaɪt fɪɾ ɪn wɪð əm əɡɛn. ʃi wɑz sɛpɝeɪt, ən ɔlweɪz wəd bi.

And their respect. If there had been any doubt that Egwene was Amyrlin, it had been dispelled. They accepted her, they feared her. And she would never quite fit in with them again. She was separate, and always would be.

ə dɪtɝmən fɪɡjɝ ɪn blu meɪɾ əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə tɛns ən əpɹoʊtʃt ɛɡwin. ðə dɪɡnəfaɪd wʊmən kɝtsiɾ əpɹoʊpɹiɪtli, ðoʊ sɪns ðeɪ wɝ wɔkɪŋ soʊ kwɪkli, ɛɡwin dɪdn stɑp tə lɛɾ əɹ kɪs ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ. "mʌðɝ," ləleɪn sɛd, "bɹaɪn sɛnz wɝd ðəɾ ɔl ɪz ət ɹɛɾi fəɹ ði əsɔlt. hi sɛz ðət ðə wɛstɝn bɹɪdʒəz wəd bi ði aɪdil pɔɪn ʌv ətæk, ðoʊ hi sədʒɛsts ðət ɡeɪtweɪz bi ɛmplɔɪd tə sɛn ə flæŋkɪŋ fɔɹs ə hɪz mɛn bɪhaɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ laɪnz.

A determined figure in blue made her way through the tents and approached Egwene. The dignified woman curtsied appropriately, though since they were walking so quickly, Egwene didn't stop to let her kiss the Great Serpent ring. "Mother," Lelaine said, "Bryne sends word that all is at ready for the assault. He says that the western bridges would be the ideal point of attack, though he suggests that gateways be employed to send a flanking force of his men behind the White Tower lines.

hi æsks ɪf ðɪs wəd bi pɑsəbəl."

He asks if this would be possible."

ɪt wɑzn juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz kloʊz. ə faɪn dɪstɪŋkʃən. bʌt biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz əbaʊt faɪn dɪstɪŋkʃənz. "tɛl ɪm əl meɪk ðə ɡeɪtweɪ maɪsɛlf," ʃi sɛd.

It wasn't using the Power as a weapon, but it was close. A fine distinction. But being Aes Sedai was about fine distinctions. "Tell him I will make the gateway myself," she said.

"ɛksələnt, mʌðɝ," ləleɪn sɛd, boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ðə pɝfəkt, lɔɪəl ətɛndənt. ɪt wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl, haʊ kwɪkli ðə wʊmənz bɛɹɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwin hæd tʃeɪnʒd. ʃi mʌst əv ɹilaɪz ðəɾ əɹ oʊnli tʃɔɪs wɑz tə ətætʃ hɝsɛlf tə ɛɡwin kəmplitli ən ɡɪv ʌp ɑn əɹ ətɛmps tə sɪkjʊɹ paʊɝ. ðɪs weɪ, ʃi dɪdn lʊk laɪk ə hɪpəkɹɪɾ ən wəd pɝhæps ɡeɪn pəzɪʃən θɹu ɛɡwin.

"Excellent, Mother," Lelaine said, bowing her head, the perfect, loyal attendant. It was remarkable, how quickly the woman's bearing toward Egwene had changed. She must have realized that her only choice was to attach herself to Egwene completely and give up on her attempts to secure power. This way, she didn't look like a hypocrite and would perhaps gain position through Egwene.

əsumɪŋ ɛɡwin wɑz eɪbəl tə steɪbəlaɪz hɝsɛlf əz ə paʊɝfəl æmɪɝlɪn.

Assuming Egwene was able to stabilize herself as a powerful Amyrlin.

ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊɾ əsʌmpʃən.

It was a good assumption.

ləleɪn mʌst əv bɪn fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd baɪ ɹoʊmændəz tʃeɪnʒ ə tɛmpɹəmənt. ðə jɛloʊ weɪɾəd bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊɾ əhɛd, əz ɪf ɑn kju. ʃi wɔɹ ə dʒɹɛs æftɝ ðə kʌlɝ ə hɝ ədʒɑ, hɛɹ bæk ɪn ə steɪtli bʌn. ʃi kɝtsiɾ əz ɛɡwin ɹitʃt əɹ ən bɛɹli spɛɹɾ ə ɡlæns fəɹ ləleɪn bɪfɔɹ fɔlɪŋ ɪndə pəzɪʃən ɑn ɛɡwinz ɹaɪt, əweɪ fɹəm ləleɪn. "mʌðɝ," ɹoʊmændə sɛd, "aɪ hæv meɪd ði ɪnkwaɪɝz jə ɹɪkwɛstɪd. ðəɹ əz bɪn noʊ kɑntækt wɪð ðoʊz sɛn tə ðə blæk taʊɝ. nɑɾ ə wɪspɝ."

Lelaine must have been frustrated by Romanda's change of temperament. The Yellow waited beside the road ahead, as if on cue. She wore a dress after the color of her Ajah, hair back in a stately bun.
