She curtsied as Egwene reached her and barely spared a glance for Lelaine before falling into position on Egwene's right, away from Lelaine. "Mother," Romanda said, "I have made the inquires you requested. There has been no contact with those sent to the Black Tower. Not a whisper."

"dʌz ðɪs stʃɹaɪk jə əz ɑd?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"Does this strike you as odd?" Egwene asked.

"jɛs, mʌðɝ. wɪð tʃɹævlɪŋ ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn ðəɹ ən bæk baɪ naʊ. ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv ət list sɛnt wɝd. ðɪs saɪləns ɪz dɪstɝbɪŋ."

"Yes, Mother. With Traveling they should have been there and back by now. They should have at least sent word. This silence is disturbing."

dɪstɝbɪŋ ɪndid. ivən wɝs, ðət dɛləɡeɪʃən kənteɪnd naɪsaʊ, maɪɹɛl, fɑoʊleɪn ən θiədʒɹɪn.

Disturbing indeed. Even worse, that delegation contained Nisao, Myrelle, Faolain and Theodrin.

itʃ ə ðə wɪmən hæd swɔɹn fiəlti tə ɛɡwin. ən ənsɛɾəlɪŋ koʊɪnsɪɾəns. ðə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ə fɑoʊleɪn ən θiədʒɹɪn wɑz pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli səspɪʃəs. səpoʊzədli, ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn kəz ðeɪ hæd noʊ wɔɹɾɝz, bʌt ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə kæmp dɪdn kənsɪɾɝ ðoʊz tu fʊl ɛɛs sədaɪ - ðoʊ noʊbɑdi wəd dɛɹ seɪ sətʃ tə ɛɡwin dɝɛkli.

Each of the women had sworn fealty to Egwene. An unsettling coincidence. The departure of Faolain and Theodrin was particularly suspicious. Supposedly, they had gone because they had no Warders, but the sisters in the camp didn't consider those two full Aes Sedai - though nobody would dare say such to Egwene directly.

waɪ hæd ðoʊz fɔɹ, aʊɾ ə ðə hʌnʒɹədz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə kæmp, bɪn pleɪst ɪn ðə dɛləɡeɪʃən?

Why had those four, out of the hundreds of Aes Sedai in the camp, been placed in the delegation?

wɑz ɪt mɪɹ koʊɪnsɪɾəns? ɪt stʃɹɛtʃt plɔzɪbɪlɪɾi. bʌt wʌɾ ɪt min, ðɛn? hæd sʌmwʌn ɪntɛnʃənəli sɛn əweɪ ðoʊz lɔɪəl tə ɛɡwin? ɪf soʊ, waɪ nɑt sɛn sɪuən? wɑz ðɪs pɝhæps ʃɛɹiəmz wɝk? ðə wʊmən hæd kənfɛs tə sɛvɹəl θɪŋz bɪfɔɹ əɹ ɛksəkjuʃən, bʌt ðɪs hædn bɪn wʌn ə ðɛm.

Was it mere coincidence? It stretched plausibility. But what did it mean, then? Had someone intentionally sent away those loyal to Egwene? If so, why not send Siuan? Was this perhaps Sheriam's work? The woman had confessed to several things before her execution, but this hadn't been one of them.

iðɝ weɪ, sʌmθɪŋ wɑz hæpənɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz æʃəmən. ðə blæk taʊɝ wəd nid tə bi dɛlt wɪð.

Either way, something was happening with those Asha'man. The Black Tower would need to be dealt with.

"mʌðɝ," ləleɪn sɛd, dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ ətɛnʃən bæk. ðə blu dɪdnt ɡlæns əɾ əɹ ɹaɪvəl. "aɪ hæv ʌðɝ nuz."

"Mother," Lelaine said, drawing her attention back. The Blue didn't glance at her rival. "I have other news."

ɹoʊmændə snɪf kwaɪətli.

Romanda sniffed quietly.

"spik," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Speak," Egwene said.

"ʃɛɹiəm wɑzn laɪɪŋ," ləleɪn sɛd. "ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil juz fəɹ dʒɹimz ɑɹ ɡɔn. ɔl ə ðɛm."

"Sheriam wasn't lying," Lelaine said. "The ter'angreal used for dreams are gone. All of them."

"haʊ ɪz ðɪs pɑsəbəl?" ɛɡwin dɪmændəd, lɛɾɪŋ ə hɪn ə hɝ æŋɡɝ slɪp aʊt.

"How is this possible?" Egwene demanded, letting a hint of her anger slip out.

"ʃɛɹiəm wɑz kipɝ, mʌðɝ," ləleɪn sɛd kwɪkli. "wi kɛp ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil təɡɛðɝ, əz ɪz kʌstəm ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ʌndɝ ɡɑɹd. bʌt . . . wɛl, wʌt ɹizən wəd ðoʊz ɡɑɹdz əv hæd tə tɝn ʃɛɹiəm əweɪ?"

"Sheriam was Keeper, Mother," Lelaine said quickly. "We kept the ter'angreal together, as is custom in the White Tower, under guard. But . . . well, what reason would those guards have had to turn Sheriam away?"

"ænd wʌt dʒju səpoʊz ʃi wɑz plænɪŋ tə tɛl ʌs?" ɛɡwin æskt. "ðɪs θɛf kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn kɛp hɪɾən fəɹ lɔŋ."

"And what do you suppose she was planning to tell us?" Egwene asked. "This theft could not have been kept hidden for long."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ, mʌðɝ," ləleɪn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "ðə ɡɑɹdz sɛd ðət ʃɛɹiəm simd . . . flʌstɝd . . . wən ʃi tʊk ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ðɪs wɑz dʒʌs læs naɪt."

"I don't know, Mother," Lelaine said, shaking her head. "The guards said that Sheriam seemed . . . flustered . . . when she took the ter'angreal. This was just last night."

ɛɡwin klɛntʃt əɹ tiθ, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ʃɛɹiəmz faɪnəl spɪl kənfɛʃənz. ðə θɛft ə ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil hæd bɪn fɑɹ fɹəm ðə moʊst ʃɑkɪŋ tɪdbɪt ʃid mɛnʃənd. ɪleɪn wəd bi lɪvɪd; ʃi hæd meɪɾ ɔl ə ðə kɑpiz ðət wɝ stoʊlən. waɪl nʌn ə hɝ kɑpiz wɝkt əz wɛl əz ði ɝɪdʒənəl, ðeɪ wɝkt wɛl ɪnʌf. ʃi wəd nɑt bi hæpi ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə hænz ʌv ə fɔɹseɪkən.

Egwene clenched her teeth, thinking of Sheriam's final spilled confessions. The theft of the ter'angreal had been far from the most shocking tidbit she'd mentioned. Elayne would be livid; she had made all of the copies that were stolen. While none of her copies worked as well as the original, they worked well enough. She would not be happy that they were in the hands of a Forsaken.

"mʌðɝ," ləleɪn sɛd, mɔɹ sɔfli. "wʌɾ ə ʃɛɹiəmz . . . ʌðɝ kleɪm?"

"Mother," Lelaine said, more softly. "What of Sheriam's . . . other claim?"

"ðæt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɪz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɪmpɝsəneɪɾɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ɛɡwin sɛd.

"That one of the Forsaken is in the White Tower, impersonating an Aes Sedai?" Egwene said.

ʃɛɹiəm kleɪmd ʃid ɡɪvən ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil tə ðɪs . . . pɝsən.

Sheriam claimed she'd given the ter'angreal to this . . . person.

ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə wɔk saɪlənli, boʊθ stɛɹɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, əz ɪf spɛkjəleɪʃən wɝ tu dɔntɪŋ.

Lelaine and Romanda walked silently, both staring forward, as if speculation were too daunting.

"jɛs, aɪ səspɛk ðət ʃiz ɹaɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðeɪ ɪnfɪltʃɹeɪɾɪd nɑɾ oʊnli əɹ kæmp, bʌt ði ɝɪstəkɹəsiz ʌv ændɝ, ɪljən ən tɛɹ. waɪ nɑt ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz wɛl?" ʃi dɪdn æd ðət vɛɹɪnz bʊk kənfɝm ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ɪt sim bɛs tə kip ði ɪkstɛn ə vɛɹɪnz noʊts sikɹət.

"Yes, I suspect that she is right," Egwene said. "They infiltrated not only our camp, but the aristocracies of Andor, Illian and Tear. Why not the White Tower as well?" She didn't add that Verin's book confirmed the presence of one of the Forsaken. It seemed best to keep the extent of Verin's notes secret.

"aɪ wʊdnt wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪt tu mʌtʃ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wɪð ði əsɔlt ɑn ðə taʊɝ, ən əɹ ɹɪtɝn, ɪt simz laɪkli ðət ðə fɔɹseɪkən - huɛvɝ ʃiz - wɪl faɪn ɪt pɹuɾənt tə slɪp əweɪ ən faɪn ən iziɝ tɑɹɡət fəɹ əɹ skimɪŋ."

"I wouldn't worry about it too much," Egwene said. "With the assault on the Tower, and our return, it seems likely that the Forsaken - whoever she is - will find it prudent to slip away and find an easier target for her scheming."

ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə dɪdn sim kʌmfɝɾɪd baɪ ðət kɑmɛnt. ðə θɹi ʌv əm ɹitʃt ði ɛdʒ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp, wɛɹ maʊns əweɪɾəd ðɛm, əz wɛl əz ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup ə soʊlʒɝz ən wʌn sɪɾɝ fɹəm itʃ ə ði ədʒəz, ʌðɝ ðən ðə blu ən ɹɛd. ðəɹ wɑzn ə blu kəz ləleɪn wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɪn kæmp; ðə ɹizən ðəɹ wɑzn ə ɹɛd wɑz ɑbviəs. ðɪs wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv waɪ ɛɡwin hæd tʃoʊzən tə wɛɹ ɹɛd, ə sʌɾəl hɪn ðəɾ ɔl ədʒəz ʃəd bi ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾ ɪn ði ækʃən ðeɪ wɝ əbaʊt tə teɪk. ɪt wɑz fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv ɔl.

Lelaine and Romanda didn't seem comforted by that comment. The three of them reached the edge of the Aes Sedai camp, where mounts awaited them, as well as a large group of soldiers and one Sitter from each of the Ajahs, other than the Blue and Red. There wasn't a Blue because Lelaine was the only one remaining in camp; the reason there wasn't a Red was obvious. This was part of why Egwene had chosen to wear red, a subtle hint that all Ajahs should be represented in the action they were about to take. It was for the good of all.

əz ɛɡwin maʊntəd, ʃi noʊɾəst ðət ɡɔɪn wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ, əɡɛn, əɾ ə ɹɪspɛkfəl dɪstəns.

As Egwene mounted, she noticed that Gawyn was following her, again, at a respectful distance.

wɛɹ hæɾ i kʌm fɹʌm? ðeɪ hædn spoʊkən sɪns ði ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ. əz ʃi maʊntəd, soʊ dɪd hi, ən əz ʃi tɝn tə ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə kæmp wɪð ləleɪn, ɹoʊmændə, ðə sɪɾɝz ən ðə soʊlʒɝz, ɡɔɪn fɑloʊɾ əɾ ə seɪf dɪstəns. ɛɡwin wɑzn sɝɾən wʌt tə də wɪð ɪm jɛt.

Where had he come from? They hadn't spoken since the early morning. As she mounted, so did he, and as she turned to ride out of camp with Lelaine, Romanda, the Sitters and the soldiers, Gawyn followed at a safe distance. Egwene wasn't certain what to do with him yet.

ði ɑɹmi kæmp wɑz moʊsli dɪzɝɾɪd. tɛns sæɾ ɛmpti, ɡɹaʊn tʃɹæmpəl baɪ fiɾ ən hʊfs, hɑɹdli ɛni soʊlʒɝz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. ɛɡwin ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs sun æftɝ livɪŋ ðɛɹ kæmp, ən ʃi hɛl tə ɪt, ɹɛɾi wɪð wivz ʃəd sʌmwʌn ətæk əɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɹaɪd. ʃi stɪl dɪdn tʃɹʌs ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wʊdn juz ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð ði əsɔlt. tʃɹu, ðə fɔls æmɪɝlɪn pɹɑbli hæɾ əɹ hænz fʊl wɪð ði æftɝmæθ ə ðə sintʃæn ətæk. bʌɾ ɛkspɛkteɪʃənz laɪk ðət wʌn - əsumɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz seɪf - wɝ wʌt hæd ɡɑɾən ɛɡwin kæptʃɝɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn. ʃi kʊdn ɹɪsk hɝsɛlf. ɪt wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ, bʌt ʃi nu ðəɾ ən ɛn hæd kʌm tə hɝ deɪz ə sɑlətɛɹi ækʃən, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ aʊɾ əz ʃi sɔ fɪt. ʃi cʊɾə bɪn kɪld, ɹæðɝ ðən kæptʃɝd, ɔl ðoʊz wiks əɡoʊ. ðə sɑlədɑɹ ɹɪbɛljən wəɾ əv flaʊndɝd, ən ɪleɪɾə wʊɾə kəntɪnjuɾ əz æmɪɝlɪn.

The army camp was mostly deserted. Tents sat empty, ground trampled by feet and hoofs, hardly any soldiers remaining behind. Egwene embraced the Source soon after leaving their camp, and she held to it, ready with weaves should someone attack her during the ride. She still didn't trust that Elaida wouldn't use a gateway to interfere with the assault. True, the false Amyrlin probably had her hands full with the aftermath of the Seanchan attack. But expectations like that one - assuming that she was safe - were what had gotten Egwene captured in the first place. She was Amyrlin. She couldn't risk herself. It was frustrating, but she knew that an end had come to her days of solitary action, striking out as she saw fit. She could have been killed, rather than captured, all those weeks ago. The Salidar rebellion would have floundered, and Elaida would have continued as Amyrlin.

soʊ ɪt wɑz ðəɾ əɹ fɔɹs ɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ðə bæɾəl laɪnz aʊtsaɪd ðə vɪlədʒ ə dɛɹn. ðə waɪt taʊɝ stɪl smoʊldɝd, ə waɪd fild ə smoʊk tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ʌp ɪn ə ɹɪŋ fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ ə ði aɪlənd, ʃɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə waɪt spaɪɹ. ivən fɹəm ə dɪstəns, ðə skɑɹz ə ðə sintʃæn ətæk wɝ ɛvəɾənt ɑn ðə bɪldɪŋ.

So it was that her force rode up to the battle lines outside the village of Darein. The White Tower still smoldered, a wide field of smoke trailing up in a ring from the center of the island, shrouding the white spire. Even from a distance, the scars of the Seanchan attack were evident on the building.

blækən hoʊlz, laɪk spɑts ə kɝʌpʃən ɑn ən ʌðɝwaɪz hɛlθi æpəl. ðə taʊɝ ɔlmoʊst sim tə ɡɹoʊn əz ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪt. ɪt hæd stʊd fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ, hæd sin soʊ mʌtʃ. naʊ ɪt hæd bɪn wundəd soʊ dipli ðəɾ ɪt stɪl blɛɾ ə deɪ leɪɾɝ.

Blackened holes, like spots of corruption on an otherwise healthy apple. The Tower almost seemed to groan as she looked at it. It had stood for so long, had seen so much. Now it had been wounded so deeply that it still bled a day later.

ən jɛɾ ɪt stʊd. laɪt blɛs ðɛm, ɪt stʊd. ɪt ɹoʊz haɪ, wundəd bʌt saʊnd, pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə sʌn hɪɾən baɪ klaʊdz əbʌv. ɪt stʊd dɪfaɪən ə ðoʊz u wəd bɹeɪk ɪt, wɪðɪn ən wɪθaʊt.

And yet it stood. Light bless them, it stood. It rose high, wounded but sound, pointing toward a sun hidden by clouds above. It stood defiant of those who would break it, within and without.

bɹaɪn ən sɪuən weɪɾəd fəɹ ɛɡwin ət ðə bæk ə ði ɑɹmi. ə dɪspɝɪt kʌpəl ðeɪ wɝ. ðə bæɾəl-hɑɹdənd dʒɛnɝəl, wɪð tɛmpəlz ʌv ɡɹeɪ ən ə feɪs laɪk ən ənjildɪŋ pis ʌv ɑɹmɝ. stʃɹɔŋ, meɪɾ ə laɪnz. ən bɪsaɪɾ ɪm sɪuən, ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv wʊmən ɪn peɪl blu, hɝ feɪs lʌvli, lʊkɪŋ jʌŋ ɪnʌf tə bi bɹaɪnz ɡɹændɔɾɝ, fəɹ ɔl ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ wɝ nɪɹ ðə seɪm eɪdʒ.

Bryne and Siuan waited for Egwene at the back of the army. A disparate couple they were. The battle-hardened general, with temples of gray and a face like an unyielding piece of armor. Strong, made of lines. And beside him Siuan, the diminutive woman in pale blue, her face lovely, looking young enough to be Bryne's granddaughter, for all the fact that they were near the same age.

sɪuən meɪɾ ə hɔɹsbæk kɝtsi əz ɛɡwin əpɹoʊtʃt, ən bɹaɪn səluɾəd. hɪz aɪz wɝ stɪl tʃɹʌbəld. hi simd əʃeɪmd ə hɪz pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə ɹɛskju, ðoʊ ɛɡwin bɔɹ ɪm noʊ ɡɹivəns. hi wɑz ə mæn ʌv ɑnɝ. ɪf i hæd bɪn bʊliɾ ɪndə kʌmɪŋ əlɔŋ tə pɹətɛk fulhɑɹɾi sɪuən ən ɡɔɪn, ðən bɹaɪn wɑz tə bi kəmɛndɪd fəɹ kipɪŋ əm əlaɪv.

Siuan made a horseback curtsy as Egwene approached, and Bryne saluted. His eyes were still troubled. He seemed ashamed of his part in the rescue, though Egwene bore him no grievance. He was a man of honor. If he had been bullied into coming along to protect foolhardy Siuan and Gawyn, then Bryne was to be commended for keeping them alive.

əz ɛɡwin dʒɔɪn ðɛm, ʃi noʊɾəd ðət sɪuən ən bɹaɪn wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ kloʊs təɡɛðɝ. hæd sɪuən faɪnəli ədmɪɾəd əɹ ətʃɹækʃən tə ðə mæn? ən . . . ðəɹ wɑz ə sɝɾən fəmɪljɝ ɡɹeɪs tə bɹaɪn naʊ. ɪt wɑz slaɪɾ ɪnʌf ðət ʃi kəɾ əv dʒʌs bɪn siɪŋ θɪŋz, bʌt kʌpəld wɪð ðə ɹileɪʃənʃɪp bɪtwin ðə tu. . . .

As Egwene joined them, she noted that Siuan and Bryne were riding close together. Had Siuan finally admitted her attraction to the man? And . . . there was a certain familiar grace to Bryne now. It was slight enough that she could have just been seeing things, but coupled with the relationship between the two. . . .

"juv teɪkən ənʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝ, ət læst?" ɛɡwin æsk sɪuən.

"You've taken another Warder, at last?" Egwene asked Siuan.

ðə wʊmən nɛɹoʊɾ əɹ aɪz. "aɪ," ʃi sɛd.

The woman narrowed her eyes. "Aye," she said.

bɹaɪn dɪd sim sɝpɹaɪzd, ən ə tæɾ əʃeɪmd.

Bryne did seem surprised, and a tad ashamed.

"du jəɹ bɛs tə kip əɹ aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl, dʒɛnɝəl," ɛɡwin sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ sɪuən ɪn ði aɪz. "ʃi hæz bɪn ɪn kwaɪɾ ə bɪɾ ʌv ɪt leɪtli. aɪ hæv hæf ə maɪn tə ɡɪv əɹ tə jə tə juz əz ə fʊt soʊlʒɝ. aɪ bɪliv ðət ðə mɪlətɛɹi ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən maɪt bi ɡʊd fəɹ hɝ, ən ɹimaɪn əɹ ðət səmtaɪmz, oʊbiɾiəns oʊvɝɹaɪdz ɪnɪʃəɾɪv."

"Do your best to keep her out of trouble, General," Egwene said, staring Siuan in the eyes. "She has been in quite a bit of it lately. I have half a mind to give her to you to use as a foot soldier. I believe that the military organization might be good for her, and remind her that sometimes, obedience overrides initiative."

sɪuən wɪltɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ əweɪ.

Siuan wilted, glancing away.

"aɪ hævən dɪsaɪɾɪd wʌt tə də wɪð jə jɛt, sɪuən," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɪn ə sɑftɝ vɔɪs. "bʌt maɪ æŋɡɝ əz bɪn kɪndəld. ən maɪ tʃɹʌst əz bɪn lɔst. jəl nid tə suð ðə fɝst ən stoʊk ðə sɛkən ɪf jə wɪʃ tə ɛntɝ maɪ kɑnfəɾəns əɡɛn."

"I haven't decided what to do with you yet, Siuan," Egwene said in a softer voice. "But my anger has been kindled. And my trust has been lost. You will need to soothe the first and stoke the second if you wish to enter my confidence again."

ʃi tɝn fɹəm sɪuən tə ðə dʒɛnɝəl, hu lʊk sɪk. pɹɑbli fɹəm biɪŋ fɔɹs tə fil sɪuənz ʃeɪm.

She turned from Siuan to the general, who looked sick. Probably from being forced to feel Siuan's shame.

"ju ɑɹ tə bi kəmɛndɪd fəɹ jəɹ bɹeɪvɝi, lɛɾɪŋ əɹ bɑn ju, dʒɛnɝəl," ɛɡwin sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə bɹaɪn. "aɪ ɹilaɪz ðət kipɪŋ əɹ fɹəm tʃɹʌbəl ɪz ə nɪɹli ɪmpɑsəbəl tʃɑɹdʒ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv kɑnfəɾəns ɪn ju."

"You are to be commended for your bravery, letting her bond you, General," Egwene said, turning to Bryne. "I realize that keeping her from trouble is a nearly impossible charge, but I have confidence in you."

ðə dʒɛnɝəl ɹɪlækst. "aɪ ʃæl də maɪ bɛst, mʌðɝ," hi sɛd. ðən i tɝn ɪz hɔɹs, ɡlænsɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊz ə soʊlʒɝz. "ðɛɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ jə ʃəd si. ɪf jə wɪl?"

The general relaxed. "I shall do my best, Mother," he said. Then he turned his horse, glancing along the rows of soldiers. "There is something you should see. If you will?"

ʃi nɑɾəd, tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs ən ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm daʊn ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. ðə vɪlədʒ wɑz kɑbəl hɪɹ, ðə pɑpjəleɪʃən ɪvækjəweɪɾɪd, ðə meɪn θɝoʊfɛɹ laɪnd wɪð θaʊzənz ə bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz. sɪuən əkʌmpəniɾ ɛɡwin, ən ɡɔɪn fɑloʊd. ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə steɪd wɪð ði ʌðɝ sɪɾɝz əɾ ə weɪv ʌv ɛɡwinz hænd. ðɛɹ nufaʊn oʊbiɾiəns wɑz pɹuvɪŋ jusfəl, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sɪns ðeɪ hæɾ əpɛɹənli dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət ðeɪ wəd naʊ bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə aʊtdu wʌn ənʌðɝ fəɹ ɛɡwinz əpɹuvəl.

She nodded, turning her horse and riding beside him down the roadway. The village was cobbled here, the population evacuated, the main thoroughfare lined with thousands of Bryne's soldiers. Siuan accompanied Egwene, and Gawyn followed. Lelaine and Romanda stayed with the other Sitters at a wave of Egwene's hand. Their newfound obedience was proving useful, particularly since they had apparently decided that they would now be trying to outdo one another for Egwene's approval.

laɪkli, ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ vaɪɪŋ tə bi hɝ nu kipɝ, naʊ ðət ʃɛɹiəm wɑz ɡɔn.

Likely, they were both vying to be her new Keeper, now that Sheriam was gone.

ðə dʒɛnɝəl lɛɾ ɛɡwin tə ðə fɹʌn laɪnz, ən ɛɡwin pɹipɛɹɾ ə wiv ʌv ɛɹ dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ən æɹoʊ wɑz ʃɑɾ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən. sɪuən aɪd hɝ, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ ət ðə pɹikɔʃən. ɪt ʃʊdn əv bɪn niɾəd - taʊɝ ɡɑɹdz wəd nɛvɝ faɪɝ ɑn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, nɑɾ ivən ɪn ə kɑnflɪk laɪk ðɪs wʌn.

The general led Egwene to the front lines, and Egwene prepared a weave of Air just in case an arrow was shot in her direction. Siuan eyed her, but said nothing at the precaution. It shouldn't have been needed - Tower Guards would never fire on an Aes Sedai, not even in a conflict like this one.

haʊɛvɝ, ðə seɪm kʊdn bi sɛɾ ʌv wɔɹɾɝz, ən æksəɾənts dɪd hæpən. ɪt wəd bi vɛɹi kənvinjən fəɹ ɪleɪɾə ɪf ə stʃɹeɪ æɹoʊ tʊk əɹ ɹaɪvəl ɪn ðə θɹoʊt.

However, the same couldn't be said of Warders, and accidents did happen. It would be very convenient for Elaida if a stray arrow took her rival in the throat.

ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ, faɪnəli kʌmɪŋ tə ə stɑp nɪɹ ðə dɛɹn bɹɪdʒ, ə mədʒɛstɪk waɪt kənstʃɹʌkʃən ðət spæn ðə ɹɪvɝ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. hɪɹ wɑz ðə θɪŋ bɹaɪn wɑntəɾ əɹ tə si: ɡæðɝd dʒʌst wɛst ə ðə haɪ pɔɪn ə ðə bɹɪdʒ, bʌŋkɝd daʊn bɪhaɪn ə blɑkeɪɾ ə stoʊnz ən lɑɹdʒ lɔɡz, wɑz ə fɔɹs ə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd. ðeɪ lʊk tə bi əbaʊt θɹi hʌnʒɹəd stʃɹɔŋ. əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz stʊɾ ətɑp ðə wɔlz. ðeɪ bɹɔt ðə toʊɾəl tə noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə θaʊzənd.

They made their way through the village, finally coming to a stop near the Darein Bridge, a majestic white construction that spanned the river to Tar Valon. Here was the thing Bryne wanted her to see: Gathered just west of the high point of the bridge, bunkered down behind a blockade of stones and large logs, was a force of Tower Guard. They looked to be about three hundred strong. Across the river, more soldiers stood atop the walls. They brought the total to no more than a thousand.

bɹaɪnz əsɔl fɔɹs hɪɹ wɑz tɛn θaʊzən stʃɹɔŋ.

Bryne's assault force here was ten thousand strong.

"naʊ, aɪ noʊ ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ nʌmbɝz ðət wɝ kipɪŋ əs fɹəm ətækɪŋ," bɹaɪn sɛd. "bʌt ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə fil mɔɹ mɛn ðən ðæt, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wɪð kɑnskɹɪpʃənz aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi pɹɑpɝ. aɪ daʊt ðeɪv bɪn spɛndɪŋ ðiz mʌnθs kɑɹvɪŋ pɛɡz baɪ ðə faɪɝ ən ɹɛmənɪsɪŋ əbaʊɾ oʊl taɪmz. ɪf tʃʌbn əz hæf ə maɪnd, hiz bɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ə nu sɛɾ ə ɹəkɹuts."

"Now, I know it was never numbers that were keeping us from attacking," Bryne said. "But the Tower Guard should be able to field more men than that, particularly with conscriptions out of the city proper. I doubt they've been spending these months carving pegs by the fire and reminiscing about old times. If Chubain has half a mind, he's been training a new set of recruits."

"soʊ wɛɹ ɪz ɛvɹiwʌn?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"So where is everyone?" Egwene asked.

"laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz, mʌðɝ," bɹaɪn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "wil luz səm mɛn ɡɛɾɪŋ pæs ðət fɔɹs, bʌt nɑt mɛni. ɪɾəl bi ə ɹaʊt."

"Light only knows, Mother," Bryne said, shaking his head. "We'll lose some men getting past that force, but not many. It will be a rout."

"kʊd ðə sintʃæn əv ɹɪli hɝɾ əm ðət mʌtʃ?"

"Could the Seanchan have really hurt them that much?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ, mʌðɝ," bɹaɪn sɛd. "ɪt wɑz bæd læs naɪt. ə lɑɾ ə faɪɝ, ə lɑɾ ə mɛn dɛd. bʌɾ aɪɾ əv pɛɡd ðə kɑst ət hʌnʒɹədz, nɑt θaʊzənz. pɝhæps ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾ ɪz klɪɹɪŋ aʊt ɹʌbəl ən stɑpɪŋ ðə faɪɝz, bʌɾ aɪ stɪl θɪŋk ðeɪɾ əv ɡæðɝɾ ə lɑɹdʒɝ fɔɹs wən ðeɪ sɔ mi fɔɹmɪŋ ʌp hɪɹ. aɪv teɪkən ə spaɪɡlæs tə ðoʊz lædz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ, ən aɪv noʊɾəd mɔɹ ðən wʌn sɛɾ ə blɪɹi ɹɛɾ aɪz."

"I don't know, Mother," Bryne said. "It was bad last night. A lot of fire, a lot of men dead. But I'd have pegged the cost at hundreds, not thousands. Perhaps the Tower Guard is clearing out rubble and stopping the fires, but I still think they'd have gathered a larger force when they saw me forming up here. I've taken a spyglass to those lads over there, and I've noted more than one set of bleary red eyes."

ɛɡwin sæt θɔtfəli, ɡlæd fəɹ ðə bɹiz bloʊɪŋ ɪn əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ fɹəm daʊnstʃɹim. "ju hævən kwɛstʃən ðə wɪzdəm ə ðɪs əsɔlt, dʒɛnɝəl."

Egwene sat thoughtfully, glad for the breeze blowing in along the river from downstream. "You haven't questioned the wisdom of this assault, General."

"ɪts nɑt maɪ hæbət tə kwɛstʃən wɛɹ aɪm pɔɪntəd, mʌðɝ."

"It's not my habit to question where I'm pointed, Mother."

"æn jəɹ θɔts ɑn ðə mæɾɝ, ɪf æskt?"

"And your thoughts on the matter, if asked?"

"ɪf æskt?" bɝn sɛd. "wɛl, ətækɪŋ meɪks tæktɪkəl sɛns. wiv lɔs tʃɹævlɪŋ əz ən ɛdʒ, ən ɪf əɹ ɛnəmi kən ɹisəplaɪ ət wɪl ən sɛn ɛnvɔɪz ɪn ən aʊt wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ wɑnt, ðən wʌts ðə pɝpəs ʌv ə sidʒ? ɪts taɪm tə iðɝ ətæk əɹ pæk ʌp ən liv."

"If asked?" Byrne said. "Well, attacking makes tactical sense. We've lost Traveling as an edge, and if our enemy can resupply at will and send envoys in and out whenever they want, then what's the purpose of a siege? It's time to either attack or pack up and leave."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. ən jɛt, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ. ðəɾ ɑmənəs smoʊk ɪn ðə skaɪ, ðə meɪm taʊɝ, ðə fɹaɪɾənd soʊlʒɝz wɪθaʊt ɹiɪnfɔɹsməns. ɪɾ ɔl sim tə wɪspɝ ə wɔɹnɪŋ.

Egwene nodded. And yet, she found herself hesitating. That ominous smoke in the sky, the maimed Tower, the frightened soldiers without reinforcements. It all seemed to whisper a warning.

"haʊ lɔŋ kən wi weɪt bɪfɔɹ jə æbsəlutli mʌs bɪɡɪn ðɪs əsɔlt, dʒɛnɝəl?" ʃi æskt.

"How long can we wait before you absolutely must begin this assault, General?" she asked.

hi fɹaʊnd, bʌt dɪdn kwɛstʃən hɝ. hi ɡlænst ət ðə skaɪ. "ɪts ɡɛɾɪŋ leɪt. ən aʊɝ, pɝhæps?

He frowned, but didn't question her. He glanced at the sky. "It's getting late. An hour, perhaps?

æftɝ ðæt, ɪɾəl bi tu dɑɹk. wɪð nʌmbɝz ðɪs feɪvɝəbəl, aɪd ɹæðɝ nɑɾ æd ðə ɹændəmnəs ʌv ə naɪt bæɾəl tə ðə mɪks."

After that, it will be too dark. With numbers this favorable, I'd rather not add the randomness of a night battle to the mix."

"wi weɪt, ðɛn, fəɹ ən aʊɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɑn əɹ maʊnt. ði ʌðɝz sim kənfjuzd, bʌt ðeɪ sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæd spoʊkən.

"We wait, then, for an hour," Egwene said, settling back on her mount. The others seemed confused, but they said nothing. The Amyrlin Seat had spoken.

wʌt wɑz ʃi weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ? wʌt wɝ əɹ ɪnstɪŋks tɛlɪŋ hɝ? ɛɡwin θɔɾ ɑn ɪɾ əz ðə mɪnəts ɪkstɛndəd, ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt hæd meɪɾ əɹ pɔz. wʌns ðɪs stɛp hæd bɪn teɪkən, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɝnɪŋ bæk. ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd sʌfɝd ðə pɹiviəs naɪt; ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ən ɛnəmi fɔɹs hæd juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ əɡɛnst ɪt. ɛɡwinz əsɔlt wəd bi ənʌðɝ fɝst: ðə fɝs taɪm wʌn ɡɹup ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd lɛd tʃɹups ɪn bæɾəl əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ ɡɹup. ðəɹ hæd bɪn faɪts bɪtwin fækʃənz ɪn ðə taʊɝ bɪfɔɹ; klæʃɪz bɪtwin wʌn ədʒɑ ən ənʌðɝ, səm tɝnɪŋ tə blʌdʃɛd, laɪk wʌt hæd hæpən æftɝ sɪuənz aʊstɪŋ. ðə sikɹət hɪstɝiz mɛnʃən sətʃ ɪvɛns.

What was she waiting for? What were her instincts telling her? Egwene thought on it as the minutes extended, eventually realizing what had made her pause. Once this step had been taken, there was no turning back. The White Tower had suffered the previous night; it was the first time an enemy force had used the One Power against it. Egwene's assault would be another first: the first time one group of Aes Sedai had led troops in battle against another group. There had been fights between factions in the Tower before; clashes between one Ajah and another, some turning to bloodshed, like what had happened after Siuan's ousting. The Secret Histories mentioned such events.

bʌt nɛvɝ hæd ðə dɪsɛnʃən ɪkstɛndəd bɪɑn ðə dɔɹz ə ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. nɛvɝ hæɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛd tʃɹups əkɹɔs ðoʊz bɹɪdʒəz. tə də soʊ naʊ wəɾ ətætʃ ði ɪvɛn fɝɛvɝ tə ɛɡwinz tɛnjɝ əz æmɪɝlɪn. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls ʃi ətʃivd, ɪt wəd laɪkli bi oʊvɝʃæɾoʊd baɪ ðɪs deɪ.

But never had the dissension extended beyond the doors of the Tower itself. Never had Aes Sedai led troops across those bridges. To do so now would attach the event forever to Egwene's tenure as Amyrlin. Whatever else she achieved, it would likely be overshadowed by this day.

ʃi hæd hoʊp tə lɪbɝeɪɾ ən junaɪt. ɪnstɛd, ʃi wəd tɝn tə wɔɹ ən səbʒəɡeɪʃən. ɪf ɪt hæd tə bi soʊ, ðən ʃi wəd ɡɪv ðə kəmænd. bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə weɪɾ əntɪl ðə læs pɑsəbəl moʊmənt. ɪf ðət mɛn ə ɡɹɪm aʊɝ bɪniθ ði oʊvɝkæst skaɪ, hɔɹsəz snɔɹɾɪŋ əz ðeɪ sɛns ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɝz' tɛnʃən, ðən soʊ bi ɪt.

She had hoped to liberate and unite. Instead, she would turn to war and subjugation. If it had to be so, then she would give the command. But she wanted to wait until the last possible moment. If that meant a grim hour beneath the overcast sky, horses snorting as they sensed their riders' tension, then so be it.

bɹaɪnz aʊɝ keɪm ən pæst. ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd fəɹ ə fju mɪnəts lɔŋɡɝ - əz lɔŋ əz ʃi dɛɹd.

Bryne's hour came and passed. Egwene hesitated for a few minutes longer - as long as she dared.

noʊ ɹɪlif keɪm tə ðə pʊɹ soʊlʒɝz stændɪŋ ɑn ðə bɹɪdʒ. ðeɪ dʒʌst stɛɹɾ aʊt bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ lɪɾəl bæɹəkeɪd, ɹɛzəlut.

No relief came to the poor soldiers standing on the bridge. They just stared out behind their little barricade, resolute.

ɹɪlʌktənli, ɛɡwin tɝn tə ɡɪv ðə kəmænd.

Reluctantly, Egwene turned to give the command.

"hɪɹ naʊ." bɹaɪn lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. "wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?"

"Here now." Bryne leaned forward in his saddle. "What is this?"

ɛɡwin tɝn bæk tə ðə bɹɪdʒ. dɪstənli, dʒʌs bɛɹli vɪzəbəl, ə pɹəsɛʃən wɑz kʌmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə tɑp. hæd ʃi weɪɾəd tu lɔŋ? hæd ðə waɪt taʊɝ sɛn ɹiɪnfɔɹsməns? hæd ʃi kɑs ðə laɪvz ə hɝ mɛn baɪ hɝ stʌbɝn ɹɪlʌktəns?

Egwene turned back to the bridge. Distantly, just barely visible, a procession was coming over the top. Had she waited too long? Had the White Tower sent reinforcements? Had she cost the lives of her men by her stubborn reluctance?

bʌt noʊ. ðət ɡɹup wɑzn soʊlʒɝz, bʌt wɪmən ɪn skɝts. ɛɛs sədaɪ!

But no. That group wasn't soldiers, but women in skirts. Aes Sedai!

ɛɡwin hɛld ʌp əɹ hænd, steɪɪŋ ɛni ətæks baɪ hɝ soʊlʒɝz. ðə pɹəsɛʃən ɹoʊd dɝɛkli ʌp tə ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən. ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, ə wʊmən ɪn ə ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs stɛpt aʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə blɑkeɪd, əkʌmpənid baɪ ə sɪŋɡəl wɔɹɾɝ. ɛɡwin skwɪntɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aʊt ðə wʊmənz fitʃɝz, ən bɹaɪn heɪstəli hændəɾ əɹ ɪz spaɪɡlæs. ɛɡwin æksɛptɪɾ ɪt θæŋkfəli, bʌt hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə wʊmən. ændaɪə fɔɹ, wʌn ə ðə nu sɪɾɝz tə ðə hɔl tʃoʊzən æftɝ ðə splɪt. ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ. ðəɾ ɪmplaɪɾ ə wɪlɪŋnəs tə nəɡoʊʃieɪt.

Egwene held up her hand, staying any attacks by her soldiers. The procession rode directly up to the Tower Guard fortification. A moment later, a woman in a gray dress stepped out in front of the blockade, accompanied by a single Warder. Egwene squinted, trying to make out the woman's features, and Bryne hastily handed her his spyglass. Egwene accepted it thankfully, but had already recognized the woman. Andaya Forae, one of the new Sitters to the Hall chosen after the split. Gray Ajah. That implied a willingness to negotiate.

ðə ɡloʊ ʌv paʊɝ sɝaʊndəd ðə wʊmən, ən sɪuən hɪst, kɑzɪŋ sɛvɹəl nɪɹbaɪ soʊlʒɝz tə ɹeɪz ðɛɹ baʊz. əɡɛn ɛɡwin hɛld ʌp ə hænd. "bɹaɪn," ʃi sɛd stɝnli, "aɪ wɪl nɑɾ əv ðə fɝst ʃɑt faɪɝɾ əntɪl aɪ ɡɪv pɝmɪʃən."

The glow of power surrounded the woman, and Siuan hissed, causing several nearby soldiers to raise their bows. Again Egwene held up a hand. "Bryne," she said sternly, "I will not have the first shot fired until I give permission."

"stæn daʊn, mɛn!" bɹaɪn bɛloʊd. "aɪl əv jəɹ haɪdz ɪf jə soʊ mʌtʃ əz nɑk ən æɹoʊ!" ðə mɛn snæp ðɛɹ baʊz bæk daʊn fɹəm ðə ɹɛɾi.

"Stand down, men!" Bryne bellowed. "I'll have your hides if you so much as nock an arrow!" The men snapped their bows back down from the ready.

ðə dɪstənt wʊmən juzd ə wiv ɛɡwin kʊdn meɪk aʊt, ən ðən spoʊk ɪn ə vɔɪs ðət wɑz ɑbviəsli æmpləfaɪd. "wi wəd spik wɪð ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ," ændaɪə sɛd. "ɪz ʃi ɪn ətɛndəns?"

The distant woman used a weave Egwene couldn't make out, and then spoke in a voice that was obviously amplified. "We would speak with Egwene al'Vere," Andaya said. "Is she in attendance?"

ɛɡwin meɪɾ əɹ oʊn wiv tə æmpləfaɪ hɝ vɔɪs. "aɪ æm hɪɹ, ændaɪə. tɛl ði ʌðɝz wɪð jə tə kʌm aʊt soʊ ðəɾ aɪ kən si ðɛm."

Egwene made her own weave to amplify her voice. "I am here, Andaya. Tell the others with you to come out so that I can see them."

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðeɪ oʊbeɪd ðə kəmænd. naɪn mɔɹ wɪmən faɪld aʊt, ən ɛɡwin stʌɾid itʃ wʌn. "tɛn sɪɾɝz," ʃi sɛd, hændɪŋ bɹaɪn bæk ɪz spaɪɡlæs ən ɹilisɪŋ əɹ wiv soʊ ðət ʃi kəd spik wɪθaʊɾ əɹ wɝdz biɪŋ pɹədʒɛktəd. "tu fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ ɪksɛp ðə blu ən ðə ɹɛd."

Surprisingly, they obeyed the command. Nine more women filed out, and Egwene studied each one. "Ten Sitters," she said, handing Bryne back his spyglass and releasing her weave so that she could speak without her words being projected. "Two from each Ajah except the Blue and the Red."

"ðæts pɹɑməsɪŋ." bɹaɪn ɹʌbd ɪz tʃɪn.

"That's promising." Bryne rubbed his chin.

"wɛl, ðeɪ kəd bi hɪɹ tə dɪmæn maɪ sɝɛndɝ," ɛɡwin noʊɾəd. "ɔl ɹaɪt," ʃi sɛd, æmpləfaɪɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs wɪð ðə paʊɝ əɡɛn. "wʌt dʒju wɪʃ ə mi?"

"Well, they could be here to demand my surrender," Egwene noted. "All right," she said, amplifying her voice with the Power again. "What do you wish of me?"

"wi hæv kʌm," ændaɪə sɛd. ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "wi hæv kʌm tə ɪnfɔɹm jə ðət ðə hɔl ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz tʃoʊzən tə ɹeɪz jə tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

"We have come," Andaya said. She hesitated. "We have come to inform you that the Hall of the White Tower has chosen to raise you to the Amyrlin Seat."

sɪuən ɡæspt ɪn ʃɑk, ən bɹaɪn kɝs kwaɪətli tə hɪmsɛlf. sɛvɹəl ə ðə soʊlʒɝz mʌɾɝd əbaʊɾ ɪt biɪŋ ə tʃɹæp. bʌɾ ɛɡwin dʒʌs kloʊzd əɹ aɪz. dɛɹd ʃi hoʊp? ʃiɾ əsum ðəɾ əɹ ənwɔntɪd ɹɛskju hæd kʌm tu sun. bʌɾ ɪf ʃid leɪɾ ɪnʌf ɡɹaʊndwɝk bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ teɪkən baɪ sɪuən ən ɡɔɪn. . . .

Siuan gasped in shock, and Bryne cursed quietly to himself. Several of the soldiers muttered about it being a trap. But Egwene just closed her eyes. Dared she hope? She'd assumed that her unwanted rescue had come too soon. But if she'd laid enough groundwork before being taken by Siuan and Gawyn. . . .

"wʌɾ ʌv ɪleɪɾə?" ɛɡwin dɪmændəd, oʊpənɪŋ əɹ aɪz, hɝ vɔɪs bumɪŋ əkɹɔs ði ɪkspæns.

"What of Elaida?" Egwene demanded, opening her eyes, her voice booming across the expanse.

"hæv jə dɪpoʊz jɛɾ ənʌðɝ æmɪɝlɪn?"

"Have you deposed yet another Amyrlin?"

ði ʌðɝ saɪd wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "ðeɪɹ kənfɝɪŋ." bɹaɪn hæd ɹeɪzd ɪz spaɪɡlæs.

The other side was silent for a moment. "They're conferring." Bryne had raised his spyglass.

ændaɪə spoʊk ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ. "ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ə ɹɔɪhən, wɑtʃɝ ə ðə silz, ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit . . . wɑz teɪkən ɪn ðə ɹeɪd læs naɪt. hɝ wɛɹəbaʊts ɑɹ ənnoʊn. ʃiz pɹəzum dɛɾ əɹ ʌðɝwaɪz əneɪbəl tə fʊlfɪl əɹ duɾiz."

Andaya spoke a moment later. "Elaida do Avriny a Roihan, Watcher of the Seals, the Flame of Tar Valon, the Amyrlin Seat . . . was taken in the raid last night. Her whereabouts are unknown. She is presumed dead or otherwise unable to fulfill her duties."

"baɪ ðə laɪt!" bɹaɪn loʊɝd ðə ɡlæs.

"By the Light!" Bryne lowered the glass.

"noʊ mɔɹ ðən ʃi dɪzɝvd," sɪuən mʌɾɝd.

"No more than she deserved," Siuan muttered.

"noʊ wʊmən dɪzɝvz ðæt," ɛɡwin sɛd tə sɪuən ən bɹaɪn. æbsənli ʃi ɹeɪz fɪŋɡɝz tə hɝ nɛk. "bɛɾɝ ʃi hæd daɪd."

"No woman deserves that," Egwene said to Siuan and Bryne. Absently she raised fingers to her neck. "Better she had died."

bɹaɪn sɛd, "ðɪs kəd bi ə tʃɹæp."

Bryne said, "This could be a trap."

"aɪ doʊn si haʊ," sɪuən sɛd. "ændaɪə ɪz baʊn baɪ ði oʊðz. ʃi wɑzn ɑn jəɹ lɪst ə blæk, wɑz ʃi, ɛɡwin?"

"I don't see how," Siuan said. "Andaya is bound by the oaths. She wasn't on your list of Black, was she, Egwene?"

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

Egwene shook her head.

"aɪm stɪl hɛzɪɾənt, mʌðɝ," bɹaɪn sɛd.

"I'm still hesitant, Mother," Bryne said.

ɛɡwin ɹɪstɔɹɾ əɹ wiv. "ju wɪl lɛt maɪ ɑɹmi ɛntɝ? jəl æksɛp ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ bæk ɪn fɛloʊʃɪp ən wɪl ɹiɪnsteɪt ðə blu ədʒɑ?"

Egwene restored her weave. "You will let my army enter? You will accept the other Aes Sedai back in fellowship and will reinstate the Blue Ajah?"

"wi æntɪsəpeɪɾəd ðiz dɪmænz," ændaɪə sɛd. "ðeɪ wɪl bi mɛt."

"We anticipated these demands," Andaya said. "They will be met."

ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns, ði oʊnli saʊn ðəɾ ə ðə wɔɾɝz læpɪŋ əɡɛns ðɛɹ bæŋks bɪloʊ.

There was silence, the only sound that of the waters lapping against their banks below.

"ðɛn aɪ æksɛpt," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Then I accept," Egwene said.

"mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛd kɔʃəsli. "ðɪs maɪt bi ɹæʃ. pɝhæps jə ʃəd spik wɪð - "

"Mother," Siuan said cautiously. "This might be rash. Perhaps you should speak with - "

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt ɹæʃ," ɛɡwin ɹilist əɹ wiv ən fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ə hoʊp. "ɪɾ ɪz wʌt wiv wɑntəd."

"It is not rash," Egwene released her weave and felt a surge of hope. "It is what we've wanted."

ʃi aɪd sɪuən. "bɪsaɪdz. hu ɑɹ jə tə lɛktʃɝ mi ɑn biɪŋ ɹæʃ?" sɪuən lʊk daʊn. "dʒɛnɝəl, pɹipɛɹ jəɹ mɛn tə kɹɔs, ən bɹɪŋ ðə sɪɾɝz ət ðə bæk fɔɹwɝd. sɛn ɹʌnɝz bæk tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp wɪð ðə nuz, ən meɪk sɝɾən jəɹ mɛn ət ði ʌðɝ bɹɪdʒəz noʊ tə stæn daʊn."

She eyed Siuan. "Besides. Who are you to lecture me on being rash?" Siuan looked down. "General, prepare your men to cross, and bring the Sitters at the back forward. Send runners back to the Aes Sedai camp with the news, and make certain your men at the other bridges know to stand down."

"jɛs, mʌðɝ." bɹaɪn wild ɪz hɔɹs əbaʊɾ ən ɡeɪv ðə nɛsəsɛɹi ɔɹɾɝz.

"Yes, Mother." Bryne wheeled his horse about and gave the necessary orders.

teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ɛɡwin kɪkt əɹ hɔɹs ɪndə moʊʃən ɑntu ðə bɹɪdʒ. sɪuən mʌɾɝd ə fɪʃɝz kɝs ən fɑloʊd. ɛɡwin kəd hɪɹ ɡɔɪnz hɔɹs fɑloʊɪŋ əz wɛl, ðən ə skwɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝz oʊbeɪɪŋ ə kɝt kəmæn fɹəm bɹaɪn.

Taking a deep breath, Egwene kicked her horse into motion onto the bridge. Siuan muttered a fisher's curse and followed. Egwene could hear Gawyn's horse following as well, then a squad of soldiers obeying a curt command from Bryne.

ɛɡwin ɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə wɔɾɝz, hɛɹ bloʊɪŋ aʊt bɪhaɪn hɝ, leɪst wɪð ɹɛd ɹɪbənz. ʃi fɛlt ən ɑd sɛns ə moʊmənt - ə weɪɾ ə ɹiləzeɪʃən - əz ʃi kənsɪɾɝd wʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl dʒʌst əvɔɪɾəd. ɪt wɑz sun ɹipleɪst wɪð ɡɹoʊɪŋ sæɾəsfækʃən ən dʒɔɪ.

Egwene rode across the waters, hair blowing out behind her, laced with red ribbons. She felt an odd sense of moment - a weight of realization - as she considered what they had all just avoided. It was soon replaced with growing satisfaction and joy.

hɝ waɪt mɛɹ bʌkt əɹ hɛd slaɪtli, bɹʌʃɪŋ ə sɪlki meɪn əkɹɔs ɛɡwinz hænz. ɑn ðə bɹɪdʒ, ðə sɪɾɝz tɝn tə meɪk ðɛɹ weɪ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. ðə taʊɝ ɹoʊz dʒʌst əhɛd. wundəd.

Her white mare bucked her head slightly, brushing a silky mane across Egwene's hands. On the bridge, the Sitters turned to make their way into the city. The Tower rose just ahead. Wounded.

bliɾɪŋ.

Bleeding.

bʌɾ ɪt stɪl stʊd. laɪt, ɪt stʊd!

But it still stood. Light, it stood!

tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɪks

CHAPTER 46

tə bi fɔɹdʒd əɡɛn æftɝ kɹɔsɪŋ ðə bɹɪdʒ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əz ə vɪktɝ, ðə deɪ nɪɹli bɪkeɪm ə blɝ fəɹ ɛɡwin. ʃi heɪsən tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, sɪuən ən ɡɔɪn bɛɹli mænɪdʒɪŋ tə kip ʌp wɪð hɝ. ət ðə taʊɝ, ɛɡwin wɑz mɛt baɪ ə ɡɹup ə sɝvəns; ðə sɪɾɝz ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə hɔl fəɹ ɛɡwin.

To Be Forged Again After crossing the bridge to Tar Valon as a victor, the day nearly became a blur for Egwene. She hastened to the White Tower, Siuan and Gawyn barely managing to keep up with her. At the Tower, Egwene was met by a group of servants; the Sitters themselves were waiting in the Hall for Egwene.

ðə sɝvəns lɛɾ əɹ tə ən ʌnədɔɹnd, wʊd-pænəl tʃeɪmbɝ sɛt wɪð ə pɛɹ ə lɛðɝ-pæɾəd tʃɛɹz. ɛɡwin hæd nɛvɝ bɪn hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ; ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə kaɪndə weɪɾɪŋ ɹum nɪɹ ðə hɔl. ɪt smɛld ə lɛðɝ, ən ə smɔl bɹeɪziɝ bɝn koʊlz ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ.

The servants led her to an unadorned, wood-paneled chamber set with a pair of leather-padded chairs. Egwene had never been here before; it appeared to be a kind of waiting room near the Hall. It smelled of leather, and a small brazier burned coals in the corner.

sun, ə ʃɔɹt, toʊdlaɪk bɹaʊn sɪstɝ neɪm lɛɹeɪn ɛntɝɾ ən ɪnstʃɹʌktəɾ ɛɡwin ɑn ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪ tə ɡoʊ əbaʊt ðə sɛɹəmoʊni. ðə lɪɾəl kɝli-hɛɹd wʊmən sim kəmplitli ɪndɪfɹən tə ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə ðə moʊmənt, ən ɛɡwin hæd nɛvɝ mɛɾ əɹ bɪfɔɹ. laɪkli, ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə bɹaʊnz u spɛn əɹ laɪf ɹoʊmɪŋ ðə bæk laɪbɹɛɹi stæks, ən oʊnli sɝfɪst wʌns ə sɛntʃɝi əɹ soʊ tə ɹəsaɪɾ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə pɹəspɛktɪv æmɪɝlənz. ɛɡwin lɪsən kɛɹfəli; ʃid ɡɔn θɹu ðə sɛɹəmoʊni wʌns, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz vɛɹi kɑmplɛks.

Soon, a short, toadlike Brown sister named Lairain entered and instructed Egwene on the proper way to go about the ceremony. The little curly-haired woman seemed completely indifferent to the importance of the moment, and Egwene had never met her before. Likely, she was one of the Browns who spent her life roaming the back library stacks, and only surfaced once a century or so to recite instructions to prospective Amyrlins. Egwene listened carefully; she'd gone through the ceremony once, but it was very complex.

ʃi kəd stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ əɹ nɝvəsnəs ɑn ðət deɪ, mʌnθs əɡoʊ, wən ʃid bɪn ɹeɪzd ɪn sɑlədɑɹ. bæk ðɛn, ʃid stɪl bɪn kənfjuzd əz tə wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. hɝ? æmɪɝlɪn?

She could still remember her nervousness on that day, months ago, when she'd been raised in Salidar. Back then, she'd still been confused as to what was happening. Her? Amyrlin?

ðət hɛzəteɪʃən wɑz ɡɔn. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli wɝi əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə sɛɹəmoʊni ɹɔŋ. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə sɛɹəmoʊni, ən ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt dɪsɪʒən hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn meɪd. əz ɛɡwin lɪsən tə lɛɹeɪn, ʃi hɝd sɪuən ɑɹɡjuɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə dɔɹz wɪð wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz, kleɪmɪŋ ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn ɹeɪzd, ən ðət ðɪs sɛɹəmoʊni wɑznt niɾəd. ɛɡwin kwaɪəɾəd lɛɹeɪn wɪð ə ɹeɪz hæn ən kɔld aʊt tə sɪuən.

That hesitation was gone. She did not really worry about getting the ceremony wrong. It was only a ceremony, and the important decision had already been made. As Egwene listened to Lairain, she heard Siuan arguing outside the doors with one of the sisters, claiming that Egwene had already been raised, and that this ceremony wasn't needed. Egwene quieted Lairain with a raised hand and called out to Siuan.

sɪuən pikt ɪn ðə dɔɹ.

Siuan peeked in the door.

"aɪ wɑz ɹeɪz baɪ ðə ɹɛbəlz, sɪuən," ɛɡwin sɛd stɝnli. "ðiz wɪmən dɪzɝv ðə tʃæns tə stæn fəɹ mi əz wɛl. ʌðɝwaɪz, əl nɛvɝ əv ə kleɪm tə ðɛɹ lɔɪəlti. ðə sɛɹəmoʊni mʌs bi pɝfɔɹmd əɡɛn."

"I was raised by the rebels, Siuan," Egwene said sternly. "These women deserve the chance to stand for me as well. Otherwise, I will never have a claim to their loyalty. The ceremony must be performed again."

sɪuən skaʊld, bʌt nɑɾəd. "vɛɹi wɛl."

Siuan scowled, but nodded. "Very well."

lɛɹeɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə kəntɪnju ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, bʌɾ ɛɡwin saɪlənst əɹ wɪð ənʌðɝ moʊʃən, ɝnɪŋ ə hʌf. "wʌt nuz əv ju, sɪuən?"

Lairain opened her mouth to continue instructions, but Egwene silenced her with another motion, earning a huff. "What news have you, Siuan?"

"wɛl," sɪuən sɛd, kɹækɪŋ ðə dɔɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪɾɝ, "bɹaɪn muv moʊst ə hɪz tʃɹups əkɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒəz, ən əz ɹɪliv ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd fɹəm ðɛɹ pəzɪʃənz ət ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃənz, sɛndɪŋ əm ɪn  - əlɔŋ wɪð ə nʌmbɝ ə hɪz oʊn skwɑdz - tə hɛlp pʊɾ aʊt flɛɹʌps ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi. ðə sintʃæn sɛt səm hoʊmz ɑn faɪɝ tə kʌvɝ ðɛɹ ɹitʃɹiɾ əz ðeɪ flɛd."

"Well," Siuan said, cracking the door a little wider, "Bryne moved most of his troops across the bridges, and has relieved the Tower Guard from their positions at the fortifications, sending them in  - along with a number of his own squads - to help put out flareups around the city. The Seanchan set some homes on fire to cover their retreat as they fled."

ðəɾ ɪkspleɪn ðə læk ə tʃɹups ət ðə bæɹəkeɪd - ðæt, əlɔŋ wɪð ðə nɑlədʒ ðət ðə hɔl wɑz bɪzi dəbeɪɾɪŋ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt tə ɹeɪz ɛɡwin. ðeɪ laɪkli dɪdn ɹilaɪz haʊ kloʊs ðeɪd kʌm tə wɔɹ.

That explained the lack of troops at the barricade - that, along with the knowledge that the Hall was busy debating whether or not to raise Egwene. They likely didn't realize how close they'd come to war.

"wʌt dʒju wɑnə də wɪð ðə sɪstɝz fɹəm jəɹ kæmp?" sɪuən æskt. "ðeɪɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə wʌndɝ."

"What do you want to do with the sisters from your camp?" Siuan asked. "They're starting to wonder."

"tɛl əm tə ɡæðɝ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə sʌnsɛt ɡeɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. "hæv əm stæn ɪn ɹæŋks baɪ ədʒɑ, wɪð sɪɾɝz ɪn ə laɪn ət ðə fɹʌnt. wʌns aɪm fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðə sɛɹəmoʊni, əl ɡɹiɾ əm ən fɔɹməli æksɛp ðɛɹ əpɑlədʒi fəɹ ðɛɹ ɹɪbɛljən ən wɛlkəm əm bæk ɪndə ðə taʊɝ."

"Tell them to gather in front of the Sunset Gate," Egwene said. "Have them stand in ranks by Ajah, with Sitters in a line at the front. Once I am finished with the ceremony, I will greet them and formally accept their apology for their rebellion and welcome them back into the Tower."

"æksɛp ðɛɹ əpɑlədʒi?" sɪuən æskt ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli.

"Accept their apology?" Siuan asked incredulously.

"ðeɪ ɹɪbɛld əɡɛns ðə taʊɝ, sɪuən," ɛɡwin sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. "wʌtɛvɝ ðə niɾ ʌv wʌt ðeɪ dɪd, ðəɹ ɪz ɹizən fəɹ əpɑlədʒi."

"They rebelled against the Tower, Siuan," Egwene said, looking at her. "Whatever the need of what they did, there is reason for apology."

"bʌt jə wɝ wɪð ðɛm!"

"But you were with them!"

"aɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɛpɹəzɛn dʒʌs ðɛm, sɪuən," ɛɡwin sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ ɹɛpɹəzɛn ðə taʊɝ. ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ. ən ðə taʊɝ nidz tə noʊ ðət ðə ɹɛbəlz ɹəɡɹɛt ðə dɪvɪʒən. ðeɪ nidn laɪ ən seɪ ðət ðeɪ wɪʃt ðeɪ hæd steɪd, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ɪts əpɹoʊpɹiət fəɹ əm tə ɪkspɹɛs sɑɹoʊ oʊvɝ ðə hɑɹdʃɪps ðə dɪvɪʒən kɑzd. əl əkwɪt ðɛm, ən wi kən ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð hilɪŋ."

"I no longer represent just them, Siuan," Egwene said firmly. "I represent the Tower. The entire Tower. And the Tower needs to know that the rebels regret the division. They needn't lie and say that they wished they had stayed, but I think it is appropriate for them to express sorrow over the hardships the division caused. I will acquit them, and we can get on with healing."

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛɾ ɪn ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən. ɛɡwin kɑt saɪɾ ə tɛzən stændɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, ðə wʊmən nɑɾɪŋ əɹ tæɹɑbənɝ-bɹeɪɾɪd hɛɾ əɾ ɛɡwinz wɝdz.

"Yes, Mother," Siuan said in resignation. Egwene caught sight of Tesan standing behind, the woman nodding her Taraboner-braided head at Egwene's words.

ɛɡwin lɛt lɛɹeɪn kəntɪnju hɝ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, ðən ɹɪpiɾɪd bæk tə hɝ ðə laɪnz ʃi wəɾ əv tə seɪ ən ði ækʃənz ʃiɾ əv tə teɪk. wən ðə bɹaʊn wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd, ɛɡwin ɹoʊz, pʊld oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən faʊn ðət sɪuən hæd lɛf tə ɹileɪ hɝ ɔɹɾɝz. tɛzən stʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd, ɑɹmz foʊldəd, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɡɔɪn. hi lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, hɪz hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz ʃið sɔɹd.

Egwene let Lairain continue her instructions, then repeated back to her the lines she would have to say and the actions she'd have to take. When the Brown was satisfied, Egwene rose, pulled open the door and found that Siuan had left to relay her orders. Tesan stood in the hallway outside, arms folded, regarding Gawyn. He leaned against the wall a short distance away, his hand resting on the pommel of his sheathed sword.

"jɔɹ wɔɹɾɝ?" tɛzən æskt ʌv ɛɡwin.

"Your Warder?" Tesan asked of Egwene.

ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɡɔɪn, ən wɑz fɔɹs tə kənfɹʌn ə hoʊl mɛs ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz. æŋɡɝ, əfɛkʃən, pæʃən ən ɹəɡɹɛt. wʌɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ mɪks. "noʊ," ʃi sɛd. ʃi stɛɹd ɡɔɪn ɪn ði aɪz. "wʌɾ aɪm gɑnə də nɛks jə kænɑt bi pɑɹɾ ʌv, ɡɔɪn. weɪt hɪɹ."

She regarded Gawyn, and was forced to confront a whole mess of emotions. Anger, affection, passion and regret. What a strange mix. "No," she said. She stared Gawyn in the eyes. "What I am going to do next you cannot be part of, Gawyn. Wait here."

hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə əbdʒɛkt, θɔt bɛɾɝ ʌv ɪt, ðən stʊɾ ʌp stɪfli ən baʊd. ðət dʒɛstʃɝ fɛlt ivən mɔɹ ɪnsələn ðən ən ɑɹɡjəmənt wəd hæv.

He opened his mouth to object, thought better of it, then stood up stiffly and bowed. That gesture felt even more insolent than an argument would have.

ɛɡwin snɪf sɔfli - jɛt laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə hɪɹ - ðən əlaʊd tɛzən tə liɾ əɹ tə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. ðə hɔl: boʊθ ə pleɪs ən ə ɡɹup ə pipəl. fəɹ ðeɪ wɝ wʌn, dʒʌst əz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz ə pɝsən, jɛt wɑz ɔlsoʊ ðə tʃɛɹ ɪn wɪtʃ ʃi sæt.

Egwene sniffed softly - yet loud enough for him to hear - then allowed Tesan to lead her to the Hall of the Tower. The Hall: both a place and a group of people. For they were one, just as the Amyrlin Seat was a person, yet was also the chair in which she sat.

ʃi stɑp bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹz tə ðə hɔl, ðə dɑɹk wʊɾ ɪnleɪd wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən fɛlt əɹ hɑɹt flʌɾɝ ɹɪbɛliəsli. sɪuən sʌɾənli əpɪɹd, wɪð ə pɛɹ ə slɪpɝz, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwinz ɹaɪɾɪŋ buts. ʌv kɔɹs; ðə hɔl flɔɹ wɑz dɛləkətli peɪntəd. ʃi tʃeɪnʒd ɪndə ðə slɪpɝz; sɪuən tʊk əɹ buts əweɪ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə bi nɝvəs! aɪv bɪn hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ, ʃi θɔt sʌɾənli. nɑt dʒʌst ɪn sɑlədɑɹ. ɪn maɪ tɛstɪŋ. aɪv feɪs ðɪs dɔɹ, kənfɹʌntəd ðə wɪmən bɪɑnd. ɪn maɪ tɛstɪŋ . . .

She stopped before the doors to the Hall, the dark wood inlaid with the silver Flame of Tar Valon, and felt her heart flutter rebelliously. Siuan suddenly appeared, with a pair of slippers, gesturing at Egwene's riding boots. Of course; the Hall floor was delicately painted. She changed into the slippers; Siuan took her boots away. There was no need to be nervous! I've been here before, she thought suddenly. Not just in Salidar. In my testing. I've faced this door, confronted the women beyond. In my testing . . .

ə ɡɔŋ sʌɾənli saʊndəd; ɪt sim laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə ʃeɪk ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ, ɹɪŋɪŋ tə wɔɹn ðəɾ ən æmɪɝlɪn wɑz əbaʊt tə bi ɹeɪzd. ðə ɡɔŋ ɹæŋ əɡɛn, ðən əɡɛn, ən ðoʊz ɔɹneɪt dɔɹz swʌŋ oʊpən. jɛs, ðɪs wɑz ə dɪfɹən ɪkspɪɹiəns ɪntaɪɝli fɹəm ðə wʌn ʃid hæd bæk ɪn ðət hʌmbəl wʊɾən bɪldɪŋ wɛɹ ʃid bɪn ɹeɪz baɪ ðə sɑlədɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪn mɛni weɪz, hɝ pɝfɔɹməns ɪn sɑlədɑɹ hæd bɪn bʌɾ ə ɹɪhɝsəl.

A gong suddenly sounded; it seemed loud enough to shake the entire Tower, ringing to warn that an Amyrlin was about to be raised. The gong rang again, then again, and those ornate doors swung open. Yes, this was a different experience entirely from the one she'd had back in that humble wooden building where she'd been raised by the Salidar Aes Sedai. In many ways, her performance in Salidar had been but a rehearsal.

ðə dɔɹz fɪnɪʃt oʊpənɪŋ, ən ɛɡwin staɪfəld ə ɡæsp. ðə ɡɹænd, doʊmd ɹum bɪɑnd naʊ hæɾ ə blæstəd hoʊl - ə ɡeɪpɪŋ ɛmptinəs - dɝɛkli əkɹɔs fɹəm ði ɛntʃɹəns. ɪt lʊkt aʊɾ ət dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt.

The doors finished opening, and Egwene stifled a gasp. The grand, domed room beyond now had a blasted hole - a gaping emptiness - directly across from the entrance. It looked out at Dragonmount.

ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɑzn əz dæmədʒd əz səm hæd bɪn ɪn ðə sintʃæn ətæk; ðə ɹʌbəl wɑz mɪnəməl, ən ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən hæd bɛɹli ɹitʃt pæs ðəɾ aʊɾɝ wɔl. ðə ɹeɪz plætfɔɹm stɪl ɹæn ɝaʊn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, ən ðə tʃɛɹz ɪt hɛld wɝ ʌndæmədʒd. eɪtin ə ðɛm, ɪn klʌstɝz ə θɹi, itʃ peɪntəɾ ən kʊʃən tə dɪklɛɹ ði ədʒɑ ʌv ɪts ɪnhæbɪɾənt.

The chamber wasn't as damaged as some had been in the Seanchan attack; the rubble was minimal, and the destruction had barely reached past that outer wall. The raised platform still ran around the outside of the room, and the chairs it held were undamaged. Eighteen of them, in clusters of three, each painted and cushioned to declare the Ajah of its inhabitant.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit stʊd baɪ ðə fɑɹ wɔl, dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə bɹoʊkən wɔl, ɪts bæk tə ðə spɹɔlɪŋ lændskeɪp bɪɑn ən dɪstən dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. ɪf ðə sintʃæn blæs hæd ɡɔn ə fju fit fɑɹðɝ ɪnwɝd, ðə sit wʊɾə bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd. θæŋk ðə laɪt, ɪt wɑz ənmɑɹd.

The Amyrlin Seat stood by the far wall, directly in front of the broken wall, its back to the sprawling landscape beyond and distant Dragonmount. If the Seanchan blast had gone a few feet farther inward, the Seat would have been destroyed. Thank the Light, it was unmarred.

ɛɡwin kəd feɪnli smɛl peɪn ɪn ði ɛɹ. hæd ðeɪ hɝidli hæd ðə sit ɹipeɪntəd tə bɛɹ ɔl sɛvən kʌlɝz əɡɛn? ɪf soʊ, ðeɪd wɝkt kwɪkli. ðeɪ hædn hæd taɪm tə ɹipleɪs ðə sits ə ðə blu sɪɾɝz, haʊɛvɝ.

Egwene could faintly smell paint in the air. Had they hurriedly had the Seat repainted to bear all seven colors again? If so, they'd worked quickly. They hadn't had time to replace the seats of the Blue Sitters, however.

ɛɡwin noʊɾəd sɹɪn, dʌsin ən jukɪɝi sɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðɛɹ ɹɪspɛktɪv ədʒəz. sin wɑz ðəɹ əz wɛl, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɛɡwin wɪð ðoʊz kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ blu aɪz. haʊ mʌtʃ paʊɝ hæd ðiz fɔɹ wɪmən wildɪɾ ɪn ðiz ɪvɛns? skwɛɹ-feɪst swænə, ʌv ðə jɛloʊ, wɑz smaɪlɪŋ oʊpənli ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən əz ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɛɡwin, ən waɪl moʊst ə ðə feɪsəz bɔɹ ðə sɝin, ʌnɪmoʊʃənəl feɪsəz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɛɡwin sɛnst əpɹuvəl ɪn ðɛɹ pɑstʃɝz. ɔɹ, ət list, ə læk ə hɑstɪləɾi. mɔɹ ðən dʒʌs ðə blæk ədʒɑ hʌntɝz hæd bɪn bɪhaɪn ðɪs dɪsɪʒən.

Egwene noted Saerin, Doesine and Yukiri sitting with their respective Ajahs. Seaine was there as well, regarding Egwene with those calculating blue eyes. How much power had these four women wielded in these events? Square-faced Suana, of the Yellow, was smiling openly in satisfaction as she regarded Egwene, and while most of the faces bore the serene, unemotional faces of Aes Sedai, Egwene sensed approval in their postures. Or, at least, a lack of hostility. More than just the Black Ajah hunters had been behind this decision.

sɹɪn stʊɾ ʌp fɹəm əɹ tʃɛɹ ɪn ðə bɹaʊn sɛkʃən. "hu kʌmz bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ?"

Saerin stood up from her chair in the Brown section. "Who comes before the Hall of the Tower?"

ʃi æskt ɪn ə ɹɪŋɪŋ vɔɪs.

she asked in a ringing voice.

ɛɡwin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, stɪl lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾɝz, ðɛɹ sits ɝeɪnʒd ɝaʊn ði aʊɾɝ plætfɔɹm, ikwəli speɪst. tu mɛni ʌv ðoʊz tʃɛɹz wɝ ɛmpti. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli tu ɡɹin sɪɾɝz; tælin hæd flɛd wiks əɡoʊ. ðə ɡɹeɪ wɝ mɪsɪŋ ɛvænɛlaɪn, hu hæd vænɪʃt ɝliɝ ɪn ðə deɪ. vɛlinə ən sɛdɔɹi wɝ ɡɔn əz wɛl. ðət dɪdn boʊd wɛl; ðoʊz tu wɝ ɑn vɛɹɪnz lɪst ə blæk ədʒɑ.

Egwene hesitated, still looking over the Sitters, their seats arranged around the outer platform, equally spaced. Too many of those chairs were empty. There were only two Green Sitters; Talene had fled weeks ago. The Gray were missing Evanellein, who had vanished earlier in the day. Velina and Sedore were gone as well. That didn't bode well; those two were on Verin's list of Black Ajah.

hæd ðeɪ bɪn wɔɹnd? dɪɾ ɛvænɛlaɪnz dɪsəpɪɹəns min vɛɹɪn hæd mɪs hɝ?

Had they been warned? Did Evanellein's disappearance mean Verin had missed her?

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɹɛd sɪstɝz iðɝ. wɪð ə stɑɹt, ɛɡwin ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət dʌɑɹə hæd lɛf ðə taʊɝ səm wiks bɪfɔɹ - noʊbɑdi nu waɪ, bʌt səm sɛɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ɑn ə mɪʃən fəɹ ɪleɪɾə.

There were no Red sisters either. With a start, Egwene remembered that Duhara had left the Tower some weeks before - nobody knew why, but some said it had been on a mission for Elaida.

pɝhæps ʃi wɑz əbaʊt blæk ədʒɑ bɪznəs. ði ʌðɝ tu ɹɛd sɪɾɝz, dʒəvɪnʒɹə ən pɛvɑɹə, hæd vænɪʃt mɪstɪɹiəsli.

Perhaps she was about Black Ajah business. The other two red Sitters, Javindhra and Pevara, had vanished mysteriously.

ðət lɛft ɪlɛvən sɪɾɝz. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹeɪz ən æmɪɝlɪn baɪ ði oʊld lɔz ə ðə taʊɝ - bʌt ðoʊz hæd bɪn ɹɪvaɪzd wɪð ɪleɪɾəz dɪsbændɪŋ ə ðə blu. fjuɝ sɪɾɝz mɛn fjuɝ wɪmən niɾəd tə ɹeɪz ən æmɪɝlɪn, ən naʊ oʊnli ɪlɛvən wɝ ɹikwaɪɝd. ɪt wəɾ əv tə du. ət list itʃ ən ɛvɹi sɪɾɝ kɝənli ɪn ðə taʊɝ nu ʌv ðɪs ɪvɛnt; ɪt wɑzn ɪn sikɹət, laɪk ɪleɪɾəz ɹeɪzɪŋ. ən ɛɡwin kəd bi ɹizənəbli sɝɾən noʊ blæk sɪɾɝz wəd stæn fəɹ hɝ.

That left eleven Sitters. Not enough to raise an Amyrlin by the old laws of the Tower - but those had been revised with Elaida's disbanding of the Blue. Fewer Sitters meant fewer women needed to raise an Amyrlin, and now only eleven were required. It would have to do. At least each and every Sitter currently in the Tower knew of this event; it wasn't in secret, like Elaida's raising. And Egwene could be reasonably certain no Black Sitters would stand for her.

sɹɪn klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin ənsɝteɪnli, ən kɔld əɡɛn, "hu kʌmz bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ?"

Saerin cleared her throat, glancing at Egwene uncertainly, and called again, "Who comes before the Hall of the Tower?"

tɛzən lin ɪn fɹəm ðə saɪd, əz ɪf tə hɪs ðə pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɑns tə ɛɡwin. ɛɡwin, haʊɛvɝ, kʌɾ əɹ ɔf baɪ hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə hænd.

Tesan leaned in from the side, as if to hiss the proper response to Egwene. Egwene, however, cut her off by holding up a hand.

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛɡwin hæd bɪn kənsɪɾɝɪŋ, sʌmθɪŋ ɑdeɪʃəs. jɛɾ ɪt wɑz əpɹoʊpɹiət.

There was something Egwene had been considering, something audacious. Yet it was appropriate.

ʃi nu ðəɾ ɪt wɑz. ʃi kəd fil ðəɾ ɪt wɑz. "ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɪz ɪn dɪsɡɹeɪs?" ʃi æskt kwaɪətli ʌv tɛzən.

She knew that it was. She could feel that it was. "The Red Ajah is in disgrace?" she asked quietly of Tesan.

ðə waɪt nɑɾəd, bɹeɪɾɪd hɛɹ bɹʌʃɪŋ ðə saɪdz ə hɝ feɪs. "ðə ɹɛdz, jə nidnt wɝi əbaʊt ðɛm," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn əɹ laɪt tæɹɑbənɝ æksɛnt. "fɑloʊɪŋ ɪleɪɾəz dɪsəpɪɹəns, ðeɪ ɹitʃɹiɾəd bæk tə ðɛɹ kɔɹɾɝz. ðə sɪɾɝz hɪɹ, ðeɪ wɝid ðət ðə ɹɛd wəd tʃuz nu sɪɾɝz kwɪkli ən sɛn əm tə ðɪs pɹəsiɾɪŋ. aɪ bɪliv səm . . . kɝt mɪsɪvz fɹəm ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ wɝ ɪnʌf tə kaʊ ðɛm."

The White nodded, braided hair brushing the sides of her face. "The Reds, you needn't worry about them," she said in her light Taraboner accent. "Following Elaida's disappearance, they retreated back to their quarters. The Sitters here, they worried that the Red would choose new Sitters quickly and send them to this proceeding. I believe some . . . curt missives from the Hall of the Tower were enough to cow them."

"æn sɪlviænə bɹɛhən? stɪl ɪmpɹɪzənd?"

"And Silviana Brehon? Still imprisoned?"

"ʃi ɪz, əz fɑɹ əz aɪ noʊ, mʌðɝ," tɛzən sɛd, slɪpɪŋ fəɹ ə moʊmən ən juzɪŋ ðə taɪɾəl, ðoʊ ɛɡwin hædn bɪn fɔɹməli ɹeɪz baɪ ðə hɔl jɛt. "doʊnt wɝi, lin - ʃiz bɪn fɹid. wi hæɾ əɹ ɛskɔɹɾɪd aʊt tə stænd wɪð ði ʌðɝ ɹɛbəlz, əweɪɾɪŋ jəɹ fɝɡɪvnəs."

"She is, as far as I know, Mother," Tesan said, slipping for a moment and using the title, though Egwene hadn't been formally raised by the Hall yet. "Don't worry, Leane - she has been freed. We had her escorted out to stand with the other rebels, awaiting your forgiveness."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. "hæv sɪlviænə bɹɔt hɪɹ, tə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ɪmiɾiətli."

Egwene nodded thoughtfully. "Have Silviana brought here, to the Hall of the Tower, immediately."

tɛzənz bɹaʊ ɹɪŋkəld. "mʌðɝ, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz ðə taɪm - "

Tesan's brow wrinkled. "Mother, I don't think this is the time - "

"dʒʌs də ɪt," ɛɡwin hɪst, ðən tɝn tə feɪs ðə hɔl. "wʌn u kʌmz oʊbiɾiəntli, ɪn ðə laɪt," ʃi pɹənaʊnst ɪn ə fɝm vɔɪs.

"Just do it," Egwene hissed, then turned to face the Hall. "One who comes obediently, in the Light," she pronounced in a firm voice.

sɹɪn ɹɪlækst. "hu kʌmz bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ?"

Saerin relaxed. "Who comes before the Hall of the Tower?"

"wʌn u kʌmz hʌmbli, ɪn ðə laɪt," ɛɡwin ɹɪspɑndɪd. ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ə ðə sɪɾɝz. ə fɝm hænd. ʃi wəɾ əv tə bi fɝm. ðeɪ niɾəd liɾɝʃɪp.

"One who comes humbly, in the Light," Egwene responded. She stared at each of the Sitters. A firm hand. She would have to be firm. They needed leadership.

"hu kʌmz bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ?" sɹɪn fɪnɪʃt.

"Who comes before the Hall of the Tower?" Saerin finished.

"wʌn u kʌmz ət ðə sʌmənz ə ðə hɔl," ɛɡwin sɛd, "oʊbiɾiənt ən hʌmbəl ɪn ðə laɪt, æskɪŋ oʊnli tə æksɛp ðə wɪl ə ðə hɔl."

"One who comes at the summons of the Hall," Egwene said, "obedient and humble in the Light, asking only to accept the will of the Hall."

ðə sɛɹəmoʊni pɹəsiɾəd, itʃ ə ðə sɪɾɝz stʃɹɪpɪŋ tə ðə weɪs tə pɹuv ʃi wɑz ə wʊmən.

The ceremony proceeded, each of the Sitters stripping to the waist to prove she was a woman.

ɛɡwin dɪd ðə seɪm, ən bɛɹli ɡeɪv ə blʌʃ ət ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɡɔɪn, hu hæd klɪɹli θɔt ʃi ʃəd bɹɪŋ ɪm əlɔŋ tə ði ɪvɛnt.

Egwene did the same, and barely gave a blush at the thought of Gawyn, who had clearly thought she should bring him along to the event.

"hu stænz fəɹ ðɪs wʊmən?" sɹɪn æskt æftɝ ðə sɪɾɝz hæd ɹeɪ-dʒɹɛst. ɛɡwin hæd tə ɹɪmeɪn stʃɹɪp tə ðə weɪs fəɹ naʊ, ən ðə kul bɹiz θɹu ðə bɹoʊkən wɔl wɑz tʃɪl ɑn əɹ skɪn. "æn plɛdʒɪz fəɹ hɝ, hɑɹt fəɹ hɑɹt, soʊl fəɹ soʊl, laɪf fəɹ laɪf?"

"Who stands for this woman?" Saerin asked after the Sitters had re-dressed. Egwene had to remain stripped to the waist for now, and the cool breeze through the broken wall was chill on her skin. "And pledges for her, heart for heart, soul for soul, life for life?"

jukɪɝi, sin ən swænə stʊd kwɪkli. "aɪ soʊ plɛdʒ," itʃ ə ðɛm ənaʊnst.

Yukiri, Seaine and Suana stood quickly. "I so pledge," each of them announced.

ðə fɝs taɪm ɛɡwin hæɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns ðɪs sɛɹəmoʊni, ʃi hæd bɪn ɪn ʃɑk. əɾ itʃ stɛp, ʃid bɪn tɛɹəfaɪd ʃid meɪk ən ɛɹɝ. wɝs, ʃid bɪn tɛɹəfaɪd ðəɾ ɪt wəɾ ɔl tɝn aʊt tə bi ə ɹuz əɹ ə mɪsteɪk.

The first time Egwene had experienced this ceremony, she had been in shock. At each step, she'd been terrified she'd make an error. Worse, she'd been terrified that it would all turn out to be a ruse or a mistake.

ðət fɪɹ wɑz ɡɔn. əz ðə ɹɪtʃuəl kwɛstʃənz wɝ æskt - əz ɛɡwin stɛp fɔɹwɝd θɹi stɛps ən nɛlt ɑn ðə smuð flɔɹ, ɹipeɪntəd baɪ ɪleɪɾəz ɔɹɾɝ wɪð oʊnli sɪks kʌlɝz spaɪɹəlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə mɑɹk ə ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn - ɛɡwin sɔ θɹu ðə pɑmp ən lʊkt ət ðə kɔɹ ʌv wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. ðiz wɪmən wɝ tɛɹəfaɪd. əz hæd bɪn ðə wɪmən ɪn sɑlədɑɹ. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz ə fɔɹs ə stəbɪlɪɾi, ən ðeɪ ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪt.

That fear was gone. As the ritual questions were asked - as Egwene stepped forward three steps and knelt on the smooth floor, repainted by Elaida's order with only six colors spiraling out of the mark of the Flame of Tar Valon - Egwene saw through the pomp and looked at the core of what was happening. These women were terrified. As had been the women in Salidar. The Amyrlin Seat was a force of stability, and they reached for it.

waɪ hæd ʃi bɪn tʃoʊzən? boʊθ taɪmz, ɪt sim ðə seɪm ænsɝ. kəz ʃi wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn ðeɪ kəɾ ɔl əɡɹi əpɑn. ðəɹ wɝ smaɪlɪŋ feɪsəz ɪn ðɪs ɡɹup. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ðə smaɪlz ʌv wɪmən u hæd səksiɾəd ɪn kipɪŋ ɹaɪvəlz ɔf ə ðə sit. iðɝ ðæt, əɹ ðeɪ wɝ ðə smaɪlz ʌv wɪmən u wɝ ɹɪliv ðət sʌmwʌn wɑz stɛpɪŋ ʌp tə teɪk liɾɝʃɪp. ænd, pɝhæps, ðəɹ wɝ səm u smaɪl kəz ðeɪ wɝn ðə wʌnz u hæd tə teɪk ðə sit. ɪts ɹisən hɪstɝi hæd bɪn fɹɔt wɪð deɪnʒɝ, dɪsɛnʃən, ən tu dʒɹəmæɾɪk tʃɹædʒəɾiz.

Why had she been chosen? Both times, it seemed the same answer. Because she was the only one they could all agree upon. There were smiling faces in this group. But they were the smiles of women who had succeeded in keeping rivals off of the Seat. Either that, or they were the smiles of women who were relieved that someone was stepping up to take leadership. And, perhaps, there were some who smiled because they weren't the ones who had to take the Seat. Its recent history had been fraught with danger, dissension, and two dramatic tragedies.

ɝɪdʒənəli, ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, ɛɡwin hæd θɔt ðə wɪmən wɝ biɪŋ ɪɾiəts. ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns naʊ, ən hoʊpfəli waɪzɝ əz wɛl. ʃi kəd si ðət ðeɪ hædn bɪn fulz. ðeɪd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ - kʌvɝɪŋ ðɛɹ fɪɹ baɪ biɪŋ oʊvɝli kɔʃəs, jɛt bɹeɪzən ət ðə seɪm taɪm. tʃuzɪŋ sʌmwʌn ðeɪ wʊdn maɪn siɪŋ fɔl. teɪkɪŋ ə ɹɪsk, bʌt nɑt pʊɾɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn dɝɛk deɪnʒɝ.

Originally, in Salidar, Egwene had thought the women were being idiots. She was more experienced now, and hopefully wiser as well. She could see that they hadn't been fools. They'd been Aes Sedai - covering their fear by being overly cautious, yet brazen at the same time. Choosing someone they wouldn't mind seeing fall. Taking a risk, but not putting themselves in direct danger.

ðiz wɪmən wɝ duɪŋ ðə seɪm. ðeɪ kʌvɝd ðɛɹ fɪɹ wɪð smuð feɪsəz ən æks ə kəntʃɹoʊl. wən ðə taɪm keɪm fəɹ ðə sɪɾɝz tə stæn ɪn əɹ səpɔɹt, ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ ɔl ɪlɛvən ɹoʊz tə ðɛɹ fit. nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl dɪsɛnt. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ fʊt wɑʃɪŋ dʊɹɪŋ ðɪs sɛɹəmoʊni.

These women were doing the same. They covered their fear with smooth faces and acts of control. When the time came for the Sitters to stand in her support, Egwene was not surprised that all eleven rose to their feet. Not a single dissent. There would be no foot washing during this ceremony.

noʊ, ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd. ðeɪ nu ðət ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ ɑpʃən, nɑt wɪð ən ɑɹmi ɑn ðɛɹ dɔɹstɛp, nɑt wɪð ɪleɪɾə əz ɡʊɾ əz dɛd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ θɪŋ tə də wɑz ækt əz ɪf ðəɹ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɛni ɑɹɡjəmənt. ðə kənsɛnsəs mʌs bi ɹitʃt.

No, she was not surprised. They knew that there was no other option, not with an army on their doorstep, not with Elaida as good as dead. The Aes Sedai thing to do was act as if there had never been any argument. The consensus must be reached.

sɹɪn lʊk sɝpɹaɪz ðət noʊbɑdi hæd tʃoʊzən tə ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd, ɪf oʊnli tə pɹuv ðət ʃi wəd nɑt bi bʊlid. ɪn fækt, mɔɹ ðən wʌn ə ðə sɪɾɝz sim sɝpɹaɪzd, ən ɛɡwin səspɛktəd ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪsɪʒən tə stæn ʌp soʊ kwɪkli. wʌn kəd ɡeɪn səm mɛʒɝ ə paʊɝ baɪ biɪŋ ði oʊnli pɝsən u ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd, fɔɹsɪŋ ɛɡwin tə wɑʃ əɹ fiɾ ən æsk fəɹ pɝmɪʃən tə sɝv. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɾ ɔlsoʊ cʊɾə sɪŋɡəl ðə wʊmən aʊt, ən ɝn əɹ ðə dɪslaɪk ə ðə nu æmɪɝlɪn.

Saerin looked surprised that nobody had chosen to remain seated, if only to prove that she would not be bullied. In fact, more than one of the Sitters seemed surprised, and Egwene suspected that they were regretting their decision to stand up so quickly. One could gain some measure of power by being the only person who remained seated, forcing Egwene to wash her feet and ask for permission to serve. Of course, that also could have singled the woman out, and earned her the dislike of the new Amyrlin.

ðə wɪmən sloʊli tʊk ðɛɹ sits. ɛɡwin niɾəd noʊ ɡaɪɾəns, ən nʌn wɑz ɔfɝd. ʃi ɹoʊz ən stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə hɔl, hɝ slɪpɝd fit saɪlən ɑn ðə peɪntəd stoʊn ə ðə fleɪm. ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn blu θɹu ðə ɹum, ɹʌfəlɪŋ ʃɔlz, bloʊɪŋ əkɹɔs ɛɡwinz bɛɹ skɪn. ɪt sɛd sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ðə hɔl ðət ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən tə mit hɪɹ, dɪspaɪt ðə dɪziɪŋ vju aʊɾ ə ðə fɑɹ wɔl.

The women slowly took their seats. Egwene needed no guidance, and none was offered. She rose and strode across the hall, her slippered feet silent on the painted stone of the Flame. A gust of wind blew through the room, ruffling shawls, blowing across Egwene's bare skin. It said something for the strength of the Hall that they had chosen to meet here, despite the dizzying view out of the far wall.

sɹɪn mɛɾ ɛɡwin ət ðə sit. ði ɑləv-skɪn ɔltɑɹən bɪɡæn tə bʌɾən ɛɡwinz bɑɾəs wɪð kɛɹfəl fɪŋɡɝz, ðən ɹɛvɝənli lɪftəd ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl fɹəm ðə sit. ɪt wɑz ðə wʌn wɪð ɔl sɛvən kʌlɝz, ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm wɛɹɛvɝ ɪleɪɾə hæd dɪskɑɹɾɪd ɪt. sɹɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɛɡwin fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hɛftɪŋ ðə stoʊl, əz ɪf dʒʌdʒɪŋ ɪt.

Saerin met Egwene at the Seat. The olive-skinned Altaran began to button Egwene's bodice with careful fingers, then reverently lifted the Amyrlin's stole from the Seat. It was the one with all seven colors, recovered from wherever Elaida had discarded it. Saerin regarded Egwene for a moment, hefting the stole, as if judging it.

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jə wɑnə bɛɹ ðɪs weɪt, tʃaɪld?" sɹɪn æskt ɪn ə vɛɹi sɑf vɔɪs. ðɪs wɑz nɑt pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɛɹəmoʊni.

"Are you certain you want to bear this weight, child?" Saerin asked in a very soft voice. This was not part of the ceremony.

"aɪ bɛɹ ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, sɹɪn." ɛɡwinz ɹɪplaɪ wɑz ɔlmoʊst ə wɪspɝ. "ɪleɪɾə kæst ɪɾ əsaɪd wən ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə slaɪs ɪɾ ən dɪvaɪɾ ɪɾ əz ʃi wɪʃt. aɪ tʊk ɪɾ ʌp ən əv kæɹiɾ ɪt sɪns. aɪ wəd bɛɹ ɪt tə maɪ dɛθ. ən wɪl."

"I bear it already, Saerin." Egwene's reply was almost a whisper. "Elaida cast it aside when she tried to slice it and divide it as she wished. I took it up and have carried it since. I would bear it to my death. And will."

sɹɪn nɑɾəd. "aɪ θɪŋk ðət maɪt bi waɪ jə dɪzɝv ɪt," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ daʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ðə hɪstɝiz wɪl kəmpɛɹ tə ðə deɪz əhɛd. aɪ səspɛk ðæt, ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ, skɑlɝz wɪl lʊk bæk ɑn əɹ deɪz ən dʒʌdʒ əm tə bi mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt - mɔɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ ə maɪnd, bɑɾi ən soʊl - ðən ðə taɪm ə mædnəs əɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪtsɛlf."

Saerin nodded. "I think that might be why you deserve it," she said. "I doubt anything in the histories will compare to the days ahead. I suspect that, in the future, scholars will look back on our days and judge them to be more difficult - more trying of mind, body and soul - than the Time of Madness or the Breaking itself."

"ðɛn ɪts ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ðə wɝld əz ʌs, ɪzən ɪt?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"Then it's a good thing the world has us, isn't it?" Egwene asked.

sɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd. "aɪ səpoʊz ɪts ət ðæt." ʃi ɹeɪz ðə stoʊl ən sɛɾ ɪɾ əpɑn ɛɡwinz ʃoʊldɝz. "ju ɑɹ ɹeɪz tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit!" ʃi dɪklɛɹd, ðə vɔɪsəz ə ði ʌðɝ sɪɾɝz dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɪn, "ɪn ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv ðə laɪt, ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ meɪ ɛndʒjʊɹ fɝɛvɝ. ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, ðə wɑtʃɝ ə ðə silz, ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit!"

Saerin hesitated, then nodded. "I suppose it is at that." She raised the stole and set it upon Egwene's shoulders. "You are raised to the Amyrlin Seat!" she declared, the voices of the other Sitters joining in, "In the glory of the Light, that the White Tower may endure forever. Egwene al'Vere, the Watcher of the Seals, the Flame of Tar Valon, the Amyrlin Seat!"

ɛɡwin tɝn tə ɹəɡɑɹd ðə ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən, ðən sæt daʊn ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ. ʃi fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɹɪtɝn hoʊm æftɝ ə vɛɹi lɔŋ dʒɝni. ðə wɝl baʊd bɪniθ ðə stʃɹɛs ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ, bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɹaɪt - ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ sɪkjʊɹ - ðə moʊmənt ʃi tʊk əɹ pleɪs.

Egwene turned to regard the group of women, then sat down in the chair. She felt as if she had returned home after a very long journey. The world bowed beneath the stress of the Dark One's touch, but it felt a little more right - a little more secure - the moment she took her place.

ðə wɪmən ɝeɪnʒd ðɛmsɛlvz bɪfɔɹ əɹ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ ʌv eɪdʒ, wɪð sɹɪn ət ðə vɛɹi ɛnd. wʌn əɾ ə taɪm ðeɪ kɝtsid dipli bɪfɔɹ hɝ, æskt əɹ pɝmɪʃən tə sɝv, ðən kɪst əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ən stɛpt əsaɪd. əz ðeɪ dɪd soʊ, ɛɡwin noʊɾəst ðət tɛzən hæd faɪnəli ɹɪtɝnd. ʃi pikt ɪn tə bi sɝɾən ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz dʒɹɛst, ðən ɹɪtɝn ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ liɾɪŋ ə ɡɹup ə fɔɹ ɡɑɹdz wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn bɝnɪŋ waɪɾ ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts. ɛɡwin səpɹɛst ə saɪ. ðeɪd bɹɔt sɪlviænə ɪn tʃeɪnz, ɪɾ əpɪɹd.

The women arranged themselves before her in order of age, with Saerin at the very end. One at a time they curtsied deeply before her, asked her permission to serve, then kissed her Great Serpent ring and stepped aside. As they did so, Egwene noticed that Tesan had finally returned. She peeked in to be certain everyone was dressed, then returned a moment later leading a group of four guards with the Flame of Tar Valon burning white on their chests. Egwene suppressed a sigh. They'd brought Silviana in chains, it appeared.

æftɝ kɪsɪŋ əɹ ɹɪŋ, ðə sɪɾɝz ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ tʃɛɹz. ðəɹ wɑz səm lɪɾəl mɔɹ tə ðə sɛɹəmoʊni, bʌt ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt pɑɹt wɑz θɹu wɪð. ɛɡwin wɑz æmɪɝlɪn, ɹɪli ən tʃɹuli, ət lɔŋ læst. ʃi hæd weɪɾəd soʊ lɔŋ fəɹ ðɪs moʊmənt.

After kissing her ring, the Sitters returned to their chairs. There was some little more to the ceremony, but the important part was through with. Egwene was Amyrlin, really and truly, at long last. She had waited so long for this moment.

naʊ ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ səm sɝpɹaɪzəz.

Now it was time for some surprises.

"ɹilis ðə pɹɪznɝz tʃeɪnz," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Release the prisoner's chains," Egwene said.

ɹɪlʌktənli, ðə soʊlʒɝz aʊtsaɪd ðə ɹum dɪɾ əz dɪmændəd, ðə mɛɾəl klɪŋkɪŋ. ðə sɪɾɝz tɝnd wɪð kənfjuzd ɪkspɹɛʃənz.

Reluctantly, the soldiers outside the room did as demanded, the metal clinking. The Sitters turned with confused expressions.

"sɪlviænə bɹɛhən!" ɛɡwin dɪklɛɹd, stændɪŋ ʌp. "ju meɪ əpɹoʊtʃ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

"Silviana Brehon!" Egwene declared, standing up. "You may approach the Amyrlin Seat."

ðə soʊlʒɝz stɛpt əsaɪɾ ən əlaʊd sɪlviænə tə ɛntɝ. hɝ ɹɛd dʒɹɛs hæd wʌns bɪn faɪn, bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn wɛl tʃɹiɾəd baɪ ɪleɪɾəz kənfaɪnmənt. hɝ blæk hɛɹ - nɔɹməli kɛpt ɪn ə bʌn - wɑz ɪnstɛd kɔɹsli bɹeɪɾɪd. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz ɹʌmpəld, ðə niz dɝɾi. ən jɛɾ əɹ skwɛɹ feɪs wɑz sɝin.

The soldiers stepped aside and allowed Silviana to enter. Her red dress had once been fine, but she had not been well treated by Elaida's confinement. Her black hair - normally kept in a bun - was instead coarsely braided. Her dress was rumpled, the knees dirty. And yet her square face was serene.

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ʃi nɛl bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin æftɝ wɔkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum. ɛɡwin loʊɝɾ əɹ hæn ən lɛt ðə wʊmən kɪs əɹ ɹɪŋ.

Surprisingly, she knelt before Egwene after walking across the room. Egwene lowered her hand and let the woman kiss her ring.

ðə sɪɾɝz wɑtʃt, kənfjuz ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd bɹoʊkən ðə sɛɹəmoʊni. "mʌðɝ," jukɪɝi faɪnəli æskt. "ɪz ðɪs ðə bɛs taɪm tə bi dɪspɛnsɪŋ dʒʌdʒmənt?"

The Sitters watched, confused that Egwene had broken the ceremony. "Mother," Yukiri finally asked. "Is this the best time to be dispensing judgment?"

ɛɡwin wɪθdʒɹu hɝ hæn fɹəm ðə nilɪŋ sɪlviænə ən lʊk dɝɛkli ət jukɪɝi, ðən tɝn əɹ ɡeɪz əkɹɔs ðə weɪɾɪŋ sɪɾɝz. "ju ɔl bɛɹ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə ʃeɪm," ʃi sɛd.

Egwene withdrew her hand from the kneeling Silviana and looked directly at Yukiri, then turned her gaze across the waiting Sitters. "You all bear a great deal of shame," she said.

stɪf-feɪst ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊz ən oʊpən aɪz waɪɾɝ. ðeɪ simd æŋɡɹi. ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɹaɪt! ðɛɹ æŋɡɝ wɑz nʌθɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɝz.

Stiff-faced Aes Sedai raised eyebrows and opened eyes wider. They seemed angry. They had no right! Their anger was nothing beside hers.

"ðɪs," ɛɡwin sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə bɹoʊkən wɔl. "ju bɛɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ ðɪs." ʃi pɔɪntəɾ ət sɪlviænə, stɪl nilɪŋ. "ju bɛɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ ðɪs. jə bɛɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ ðə weɪ əɹ sɪstɝz ɹəɡɑɹd wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə hɔlz, ən jə bɛɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ɹɪmeɪn soʊ lɔŋ ɪn dɪvɪʒən. mɛni ʌv jə bɛɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ ðət dɪvɪʒən ɑn ðə fɝs pleɪs!

"This," Egwene said, gesturing toward the broken wall. "You bear responsibility for this." She pointed at Silviana, still kneeling. "You bear responsibility for this. You bear responsibility for the way our sisters regard one another in the halls, and you bear responsibility for letting the Tower remain so long in division. Many of you bear responsibility for that division on the first place!

"ju ɑɹ ə dɪsɡɹeɪs. ðə waɪt taʊɝ - ðə pɹaɪɾ ə ðə laɪt, ðə paʊɝ fəɹ stəbɪlɪɾi ən tʃɹuθ sɪns ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz - hæz nɪɹli bɪn ʃæɾɝd kəz ə ju."

"You are a disgrace. The White Tower - the pride of the Light, the power for stability and truth since the Age of Legends - has nearly been shattered because of you."

aɪz bʌɡd aʊt, ən ə fju wɪmən tʃoʊkt ɪn ʃɑk. "ɪleɪɾə - " wʌn bɪɡæn.

Eyes bugged out, and a few women choked in shock. "Elaida - " one began.

"ɪleɪɾə wɑz ə mædwʊmən, ən jə ɔl noʊ ɪt!" ɛɡwin sɛd stɝnli, stændɪŋ tɔl, stɛɹɪŋ əm daʊn. "ju nu ɪt ðiz læs fju mʌnθs əz ʃi wɝkt ənwɪɾɪŋli tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ʌs. laɪt, mɛni ʌv jə pɹɑbli nu ɪt wən jə ɹeɪzd əɹ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs!

"Elaida was a madwoman, and you all know it!" Egwene said sternly, standing tall, staring them down. "You knew it these last few months as she worked unwittingly to destroy us. Light, many of you probably knew it when you raised her in the first place!

"ðɛɹ əv bɪn fulɪʃ æmɪɝlənz bɪfɔɹ, bʌt nʌn əv kʌm əz kloʊs tə tɛɹɪŋ daʊn ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ! jə ɑɹ ə tʃɛk əpɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn. jə ɑɹ tə kip əɹ fɹəm duɪŋ θɪŋz laɪk ðɪs! jə əlaʊɾ əɹ tə dɪsbæn ən ɪntaɪɝ ədʒɑ? wʌt wɝ jə θɪŋkɪŋ? haʊ ɪz ɪt ðət jə əlaʊd ðə taʊɝ tə fɔl soʊ fɑɹ? ən wən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɪmsɛlf wɔks ðə lænd, noʊ lɛs!

"There have been foolish Amyrlins before, but none have come as close to tearing down the entire Tower! You are a check upon the Amyrlin. You are to keep her from doing things like this! You allowed her to disband an entire Ajah? What were you thinking? How is it that you allowed the Tower to fall so far? And when the Dragon Reborn himself walks the land, no less!

"ju ʃʊɾə ɹimuvd ɪleɪɾə ðə moʊmən jə hɝɾ ə hɝ dɪzæstʃɹəs ətɛmp tə kənfaɪn ɹænd ælθɹ. jə ʃʊɾə ɹimuvd əɹ wən jə sɔ haʊ hɝ bɪkɝɪŋ ən pɛɾinəs wɑz tɝnɪŋ ədʒəz əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ. ən jə ʃəd sɝɾənli hæv ɹimuvd əɹ wən ʃi ɹəfjuz tə də wʌt wɑz niɾəd tə bɹɪŋ ðə taʊɝ təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn, hoʊl əz wʌn!"

"You should have removed Elaida the moment you heard of her disastrous attempt to confine Rand al'Thor. You should have removed her when you saw how her bickering and pettiness was turning Ajahs against one another. And you should certainly have removed her when she refused to do what was needed to bring the Tower together again, whole as one!"

ɛɡwin lʊk daʊn ðə laɪnz ə sɪstɝz, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ itʃ wʌn ɪn tɝn, miɾɪŋ itʃ sɛɾ ʌv aɪz əntɪl ðeɪ lʊkt əweɪ. nʌn dɛɹd hoʊld əɹ ɡeɪz fəɹ lɔŋ. faɪnəli, ʃi sɔ ʃeɪm bɪɡɪn tə pik θɹu ðɛɹ mæsks. əz wɛl ɪt ʃʊd!

Egwene looked down the lines of sisters, staring at each one in turn, meeting each set of eyes until they looked away. None dared hold her gaze for long. Finally, she saw shame begin to peek through their masks. As well it should!

"nʌn ə jə wəd stæn ʌp tə hɝ," ɛɡwin spæt. "ju dɛɹ kɔl jɝsɛlf ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ? jə hu wɝ kaʊd? jə hu wɝ tu fɹaɪɾənd tə də wʌt wɑz niɾəd? jə hu wɝ tu kɑɾ ʌp ɪn jəɹ oʊn skwɑbəlz ən pɑlətɪkɪŋ tə si wʌt wɑz niɾəd?"

"None of you would stand up to her," Egwene spat. "You dare call yourself the Hall of the Tower? You who were cowed? You who were too frightened to do what was needed? You who were too caught up in your own squabbles and politicking to see what was needed?"

ɛɡwin lʊk daʊn ət sɪlviænə. "oʊnli wʌn wʊmən ɪn ðɪs ɹum wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə stæn ʌp fəɹ wʌt ʃi nu tə bi ɹaɪt. oʊnli wʌn wʊmən dɛɹd dɪfaɪ ɪleɪɾə, ən ʃi æksɛptɪd ðə pɹaɪs ə duɪŋ soʊ. ən jə θɪŋk aɪ bɹɔt ðɪs wʊmən hɪɹ tə ɪɡzæk vɛnʒəns ɑn hɝ? ɑɹ jə ɹɪli soʊ blaɪndɪd ðət jə θɪŋk aɪd pʌnɪʃ ði oʊnli pɝsən ɪn ði ɪntaɪɝ taʊɝ u dɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ə disənsi ðiz læs fju mʌnθs?"

Egwene looked down at Silviana. "Only one woman in this room was willing to stand up for what she knew to be right. Only one woman dared defy Elaida, and she accepted the price of doing so. And you think I brought this woman here to exact vengeance on her? Are you really so blinded that you think I'd punish the only person in the entire Tower who did anything of decency these last few months?"

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl lʊkɪŋ daʊn, naʊ. ivən sɹɪn wʊdn miɾ əɹ aɪz.

They were all looking down, now. Even Saerin wouldn't meet her eyes.

sɪlviænə lʊkt ʌp ət hɝ.

Silviana looked up at her.

"ju dɪd jəɹ duɾi, sɪlviænə," ɛɡwin sɛd. "æn jə dɪɾ ɪt wɛl. ɹaɪz."

"You did your duty, Silviana," Egwene said. "And you did it well. Rise."

ðə wʊmən stʊd. ʃi lʊk hæɡɝd, aɪz pʌfi fɹəm læk ə slip, ən ɛɡwin səspɛktəd ʃi wɑz hævɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl stændɪŋ. hæɾ ɛniwʌn sin tə bɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ fuɾ əɹ wɔɾɝ dʊɹɪŋ ðə keɪɑs ə ðə læs fju deɪz?

The woman stood. She looked haggard, eyes puffy from lack of sleep, and Egwene suspected she was having trouble standing. Had anyone seen to bringing her food or water during the chaos of the last few days?

"sɪlviænə," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ə nu æmɪɝlɪn əz bɪn ɹeɪzd. ænd, ɪt ʃeɪmz mi tə seɪ, ɪt wɑz dʌn wɪð sʌbtɝfjudʒ sɪməlɝ tə ɪleɪɾəz ɹeɪzɪŋ. ʌv ðə sɛvən ədʒəz, oʊnli faɪv wɝ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd. ðə blu aɪ noʊ wəd səpɔɹt mi, wɝ ðeɪ hɪɹ. bʌt ðə ɹɛd wɝ nɑɾ ivən ɡɪvən ə tʃæns tə vɔɪs ðɛɹ dɪsɛn əɹ əpɹuvəl."

"Silviana," Egwene said, "a new Amyrlin has been raised. And, it shames me to say, it was done with subterfuge similar to Elaida's raising. Of the seven Ajahs, only five were represented. The Blue I know would support me, were they here. But the Red were not even given a chance to voice their dissent or approval."

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɡʊd ɹizənz fəɹ ðæt, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd.

"There are good reasons for that, Mother," Silviana said.

"ðæt meɪ bi tʃɹu," ɛɡwin sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔl bʌɾ ɛnʃʊɹz ðət maɪ ɹeɪn wɪl bi mɑɹkt wɪð tɛnʃən bɪtwin maɪsɛlf ən ðə ɹɛd. ðəl pɝsiv ɪl wɪl wɛɹ ðəɹ ɪz nʌn, ən əl luz ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə hʌnʒɹədz ʌv wɪmən. wɪmən ðət wɪl bi sɔɹli niɾəd."

"That may be true," Egwene said, "but it all but ensures that my reign will be marked with tension between myself and the Red. They will perceive ill will where there is none, and I will lose the strength of hundreds of women. Women that will be sorely needed."

"aɪ . . . doʊn si ɛni weɪ ɝaʊn ðæt, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd, ɑnəsli.

"I . . . don't see any way around that, Mother," Silviana said, honestly.

"aɪ du," ɛɡwin sɛd. "sɪlviænə bɹɛhən, aɪ wəɾ əv jə əz maɪ kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz. lɛɾ ɪt nɑt bi sɛd ðəɾ aɪ spɝn ðə ɹɛd."

"I do," Egwene said. "Silviana Brehon, I would have you as my Keeper of the Chronicles. Let it not be said that I spurned the Red."

sɪlviænə blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ðəɹ wɝ ə fju ɡæsps fɹəm ðə sɪɾɝz, ðoʊ ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt mɑɹk huz ðeɪ wɝ.

Silviana blinked in surprise. There were a few gasps from the Sitters, though Egwene did not mark whose they were.

ʃi stɛɹd sɪlviænə ɪn ði aɪz. dʒʌst ə ʃɔɹt taɪm əɡoʊ, ðɪs wʊmən hæd hæɾ ɛɡwin oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə dɛsk, pæɾəlɪŋ əɹ əɾ ɪleɪɾəz kəmænd. bʌt sɪlviænə naʊ nɛlt; ʃi hæd dʌn soʊ wɪθaʊt niɾɪŋ ən ɔɹɾɝ. ʃi æksɛptɪd ðə hɔlz əθɔɹəɾi tə ɹeɪz ɛɡwin. dɪd ʃi æksɛpt ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf?

She stared Silviana in the eyes. Just a short time ago, this woman had had Egwene over the side of the desk, paddling her at Elaida's command. But Silviana now knelt; she had done so without needing an order. She accepted the Hall's authority to raise Egwene. Did she accept Egwene herself?

ɛɡwinz ɔfɝ wəd pleɪs əɹ ɑn ə dɪfəkəlt ən deɪnʒɝəs ɹoʊd. ðə ɹɛdz maɪt si ɪɾ əz ə bɪtʃɹeɪəl. wʌt wəd sɪlviænəz ɹɪspɑns bi? ɛɡwin blɛs ðə tʃɹɪk ðət kɛpt əɹ fɹəm swɛɾɪŋ, ʌðɝwaɪz ʃi nu ðət dʒɹɑps wʊɾə bɪn tʃɹɪklɪŋ daʊn ðə saɪdz ə hɝ feɪs.

Egwene's offer would place her on a difficult and dangerous road. The Reds might see it as a betrayal. What would Silviana's response be? Egwene blessed the trick that kept her from sweating, otherwise she knew that drops would have been trickling down the sides of her face.

"aɪ wəd bi ɑnɝd, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd, nilɪŋ əɡɛn. "tʃɹuli ɑnɝd."

"I would be honored, Mother," Silviana said, kneeling again. "Truly honored."

ɛɡwin lɛɾ aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ. hɝ tæsk ə ɹiunaɪɾɪŋ ðə fɹæktʃɝɾ ədʒəz wəd bi dɪfəkəlt - bʌɾ ɪf ðə ɹɛdz sɔ hɝ əz ən ɛnəmi, ɪt wəd bi nɪɹli ɪmpɑsəbəl. wɪð sɪlviænə ɑn əɹ saɪd, ʃi wəɾ əv ən ɛnvɔɪ tə ðə ɹɛdz u wəd nɑt bi ɹɪdʒɛktɪd. hoʊpfəli.

Egwene let out a breath. Her task of reuniting the fractured Ajahs would be difficult - but if the Reds saw her as an enemy, it would be nearly impossible. With Silviana on her side, she would have an envoy to the Reds who would not be rejected. Hopefully.

"ðɪs wɪl bi ə dɪfəkəl taɪm fəɹ ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, dɔɾɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðɛɹ neɪtʃɝ əz ɔlweɪz bɪn tə kæptʃɝ mɛn u kən tʃænəl, bʌt ɹɪpɔɹts kleɪm ðət seɪɾɪn ɪz klɛnzd."

"This will be a difficult time for the Red Ajah, daughter," Egwene said. "Their nature has always been to capture men who can channel, but reports claim that saidin is cleansed."

"ðɛɹ wɪl stɪl bi ɹoʊɡ tʃænlɝz, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd. "æn mɛn ɑɹ nɑt tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd."

"There will still be rogue channelers, Mother," Silviana said. "And men are not to be trusted."

sʌmdeɪ, wɪl əv tə muv bɪɑn ðət læst sɛntəmənt, ɛɡwin θɔt. bʌt fəɹ naʊ, ɪts tʃɹu ɪnʌf tə lɛt stænd. "aɪ dɪdn seɪ ðət jəɹ pɝpəs wəd vænɪʃ, oʊnli ðəɾ ɪt wəd tʃeɪnʒ. aɪ si ɡɹeɪt θɪŋz fəɹ ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ - ən ɪkspændɪŋ ə vɪʒən, ə ɹɪnuəl ə duɾi. aɪm pliz tə hæv jə ət maɪ saɪd tə hɛlp ɡaɪd ðɛm."

Someday, we will have to move beyond that last sentiment, Egwene thought. But for now, it is true enough to let stand. "I didn't say that your purpose would vanish, only that it would change. I see great things for the Red Ajah in the future - an expanding of vision, a renewal of duty. I am pleased to have you at my side to help guide them."

ɛɡwin lʊkt ʌp ət ðə sɪɾɝz, hu wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ɪn stʌn saɪləns. "aɪɾ ɔɹɾɝ jə ɔl tə də pɛnəns," ɛɡwin sɛd, "seɪv fəɹ ðə fæk ðəɾ aɪ noʊ səm ə ju, ət list, wɝ wɝkɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə sinz tə stɑp ðə kɹʌmbəlɪŋ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. jə dɪdn də ɪnʌf, bʌt jə dɪd sʌmθɪŋ.

Egwene looked up at the Sitters, who were watching in stunned silence. "I'd order you all to do penance," Egwene said, "save for the fact that I know some of you, at least, were working behind the scenes to stop the crumbling of the White Tower. You didn't do enough, but you did something.

bɪɑn ðæt, aɪ θɪŋk ðət ðə pɛnəns wi ɔfən dɪmæn ʌv aʊɝsɛlvz ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs. wʌɾ ɪz fɪzɪkəl peɪn tə ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

Beyond that, I think that the penance we often demand of ourselves is ridiculous. What is physical pain to Aes Sedai?"

ɛɡwin tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "æn aɪm nɑt ɡɪltləs iðɝ. aɪ ʃɛɹ səm ə jəɹ ʃeɪm, fəɹ ɪt wɑz dʊɹɪŋ maɪ tɛnjɝ ðət ðiz dɪzæstɝz əkɝd. aɪ saɪɾəd wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz, əlaʊd maɪsɛlf tə bi ɹeɪz baɪ ðɛm kəz ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli tʃɔɪs. bʌt ðət tʃɔɪs stɪl ɡɪvz mi kʌlpəbɪlɪɾi.

Egwene took a deep breath. "And I am not guiltless either. I share some of your shame, for it was during my tenure that these disasters occurred. I sided with the rebels, allowed myself to be raised by them because it was the only choice. But that choice still gives me culpability.
