"bɛɹ jəɹ ʃeɪm, sɪɾɝz, bʌt bɛɹ ɪt wɪð dɪtɝməneɪʃən. də nɑt lɛɾ ɪt bɹeɪk ju. ðə taɪm fəɹ hilɪŋ əz bɪɡʌn, ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛni jus ɪn pɔɪntɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz. jə feɪld. bʌt jə ɑɹ ɔl ðət wi hæv. wəɹ ɔl ðət ðə wɝl hæz."

"Bear your shame, Sitters, but bear it with determination. Do not let it break you. The time for healing has begun, and there is no longer any use in pointing fingers. You failed. But you are all that we have. We are all that the world has."

ðə wɪmən bɪɡæn tə lʊk ʌp.

The women began to look up.

"kʌm," ɛɡwin sɛd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹum, sɪlviænə smuðli fɔlɪŋ ɪndə stɛp bɪsaɪd hɝ.

"Come," Egwene said, striding through the room, Silviana smoothly falling into step beside her.

"lɛɾ əs ɡɹit ðə ɹɛbəlz."

"Let us greet the rebels."

ðeɪ pæs θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz ə ðə taʊɝ, wɪtʃ stɪl smɛld ə smoʊk ən wɝ stʃɹun wɪð ɹʌbəl ɪn pleɪsəz. ɛɡwin tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə blʌdsteɪnz. ðə sɪɾɝz fɑloʊd bɪhaɪnd, klʌstɝɪŋ ɪn ədʒɑ ɡɹups, dɪspaɪɾ ɛɡwinz ɹisən tʃæstaɪsmənt. ðəɹ wəd stɪl bi ə lɑɾ ʌv wɝk tə hil ðɛm.

They passed through the hallways of the Tower, which still smelled of smoke and were strewn with rubble in places. Egwene tried not to look at the bloodstains. The Sitters followed behind, clustering in Ajah groups, despite Egwene's recent chastisement. There would still be a lot of work to heal them.

"mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd kwaɪətli əz ðeɪ wɔkt, "aɪ kən oʊnli əsum ðət jə hæɾ ə kipɝ ɔlɹɛɾi, əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəlz. dʒju ɪntɛn tə meɪnteɪn tu ʌv ʌs?" hɝ tɛns vɔɪs ɹɪvild wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə sətʃ ən ʌnkənvɛnʃənəl ɝeɪnʒmənt.

"Mother," Silviana said quietly as they walked, "I can only assume that you had a Keeper already, among the rebels. Do you intend to maintain two of us?" Her tense voice revealed what she thought of such an unconventional arrangement.

"noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "maɪ pɹiviəs kipɝ wɑz ɛksəkjuɾəd fəɹ biɪŋ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ."

"No," Egwene said. "My previous Keeper was executed for being of the Black Ajah."

sɪlviænə peɪld. "aɪ si."

Silviana paled. "I see."

"wi kæn dæns ɝaʊn ðiz θɪŋz, sɪlviænə," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ ɹəsivd ə vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt vɪzəɾɝ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ maɪ . . . ɹɛskju. ʃi wɑz ə ðə blæk, ən bɪtʃɹeɪd tə mi ðə neɪmz ʌv ʌðɝ blæk sɪstɝz.

"We can't dance around these things, Silviana," Egwene said. "I received a very important visitor just before my . . . rescue. She was of the Black, and betrayed to me the names of other Black sisters.

aɪ hæv kənfɝmd itʃ ə ðoʊz u wɝ əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ θɹu jus ə ði oʊθ ɹɑd."

I have confirmed each of those who were among the rebel Aes Sedai through use of the Oath Rod."

"ði oʊθ ɹɑd?" sɪlviænə ɪkskleɪmd.

"The Oath Rod?" Silviana exclaimed.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɛntɝɾ ə stɛɹwɛl. "aɪ wɑz ɡɪvən ɪt læs naɪt baɪ ən ælaɪ ɪn ðə taʊɝ.

"Yes," Egwene said as they entered a stairwell. "I was given it last night by an ally in the Tower.

ðoʊ, ɪɾ əkɝz tə mi ðət wɪl əv tə muv ðə ɹum wɪð ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ən kip ðə loʊkeɪʃən sikɹəɾ ən kɑnstənli wɔɹɾɪd. ɪt woʊn bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɛvɹi sɪstɝ wɪð səfɪʃən paʊɝ noʊz ðə wiv fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ, ən aɪ wʊdn pʊɾ ɪt pæs mɛni ʌv əm - ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðoʊz aɪ tʃɹʌst - tə 'bɑɹoʊ'

Though, it occurs to me that we'll have to move the room with the ter'angreal. And keep the location secret and constantly warded. It won't be long before every sister with sufficient power knows the weave for Traveling, and I wouldn't put it past many of them - including those I trust - to 'borrow'

æŋɡɹil naʊ ən əɡɛn."

angreal now and again."

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd. ðɛn, ɪn ə kwaɪəɾɝ vɔɪs. "aɪm gɑnə hæv tə ɡɛt juz tə ə lɑɾ ə θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, aɪ səspɛkt."

"Yes, Mother," Silviana said. Then, in a quieter voice. "I'm going to have to get used to a lot of things changing, I suspect."

"aɪm əfɹeɪd soʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "nɑt ðə list ʌv wɪtʃ wɪl bi ðə nid tə tʃuz ə pɹɑpɝ mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, wʌn u kən dil wɪð hʌnʒɹədz ə nu ɪnɪʃieɪts - mɛni ʌv hum ɑɹ nɑɾ ə ðə stændɝɾ eɪdʒ. aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn ðə pɹɑsɛs ʌv æksɛptɪŋ fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɛni wʊmən, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ oʊld, hu ʃoʊz səm mɛʒɝ ʌv əbɪləɾi wɪð tʃænəlɪŋ. aɪ səspɛk ðət bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɪl bi bɝstɪŋ ət ðə simz wɪð nɑvəsɪz."

"I'm afraid so," Egwene said. "Not the least of which will be the need to choose a proper Mistress of Novices, one who can deal with hundreds of new initiates - many of whom are not of the standard age. I've already begun the process of accepting for training any woman, no matter how old, who shows some measure of ability with channeling. I suspect that before long, the White Tower will be bursting at the seams with novices."

"aɪ ʃæl kənsɪɾɝ sədʒɛstʃənz fəɹ ə ɹɪpleɪsmən kwɪkli ðɛn, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd.

"I shall consider suggestions for a replacement quickly then, Mother," Silviana said.

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd ɪn əpɹuvəl. ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn wəɾ əndaʊɾɪdli bi lɪvɪd wən ðeɪ dɪskʌvɝd wʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd dʌn ɪn tʃuzɪŋ sɪlviænə, bʌt ðə mɔɹ ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ɪt, ðə mɔɹ sæɾəsfaɪd ɛɡwin wɑz. nɑt dʒʌs kəz sɪlviænə wɑz ɹɛd, bʌt kəz ʃi wɑz soʊ keɪpəbəl. sɹɪn wʊɾə bɪn ə fɛɹ tʃɔɪs, bʌt mɛni wʊɾə sin əɹ əz biɪŋ ɛɡwinz ɡaɪd, ən pɝhæps ðə ɹil paʊɝ bɪhaɪn ðə sit. pɪkɪŋ ə blu wʊɾə bɪn tu dɪvaɪsɪv fəɹ ðə kɝən steɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ. ən bɪsaɪdz, wɪð ən æmɪɝlɪn u wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɹɛbəlz - noʊbɑdi wəd sun fɝɡɛt ðæt, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɛɡwin sɛɾ əɹ dɪd - ɪt wəd ɡoʊ ə lɔŋ weɪ təwɔɹd hilɪŋ ɹileɪʃənz tə hæv ə kipɝ u hæd bɪn ə lɔɪəlɪst.

Egwene nodded in approval. Romanda and Lelaine would undoubtedly be livid when they discovered what Egwene had done in choosing Silviana, but the more she considered it, the more satisfied Egwene was. Not just because Silviana was Red, but because she was so capable. Saerin would have been a fair choice, but many would have seen her as being Egwene's guide, and perhaps the real power behind the Seat. Picking a Blue would have been too divisive for the current state of the Tower. And besides, with an Amyrlin who was one of the rebels - nobody would soon forget that, no matter what Egwene said or did - it would go a long way toward healing relations to have a Keeper who had been a loyalist.

bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə taʊɝz ɡɹeɪt skwɛɹ, ɑn ði ist saɪɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ. ðə skwɛɹ wɑz fɪld - əz pɝ əɹ ɔɹɾɝz - baɪ wɪmən ɪn ɹæŋks baɪ ədʒɑ. ɛɡwin hæd tʃoʊzən ðɪs pəzɪʃən kəz ə ðə tɔl stɛps liɾɪŋ ʌp tə ðə taʊɝ, tɑp baɪ ə speɪʃəs lændɪŋ. ʃi stʊd ðɛɹ, bæk tə ðə mədʒɛstɪkəli kɑɹv dɔɹz. ɪt wɑz ə pɝfək loʊkeɪʃən fɹəm wɪtʃ tə ædʒɹɛs ə kɹaʊd.

Before long, they reached the Tower's Great Square, on the east side of the building. The square was filled - as per her orders - by women in ranks by Ajah. Egwene had chosen this position because of the tall steps leading up to the Tower, topped by a spacious landing. She stood there, back to the majestically carved doors. It was a perfect location from which to address a crowd.

ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ sɪtʃueɪɾɪd bɪtwin ðə wɪŋz, wɪtʃ hæd teɪkən ðə wɝs dæmədʒ dʊɹɪŋ ði ətæk ðə pɹiviəs naɪt. ði ist wɪŋ stɪl smoʊldɝd; ðə doʊm hæd kəlæpst; wʌn ə ðə wɔlz hæd fɔlən ɪn.

It was also situated between the wings, which had taken the worst damage during the attack the previous night. The east wing still smoldered; the dome had collapsed; one of the walls had fallen in.

haʊɛvɝ, fɹəm ðɪs væntədʒ, ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf wɑz ɹɛləɾɪvli fɹi ʌv skɑɹz, ən niðɝ ə ðə ɡeɪpɪŋ hoʊlz wɑz dɝɛkli vɪzəbəl.

However, from this vantage, the Tower itself was relatively free of scars, and neither of the gaping holes was directly visible.

ɛɡwin kəd si feɪsəz laɪnɪŋ ðə loʊɝ wɪndoʊz. ɛɛs sədaɪ ən nɑvəsɪz əlaɪk wɑtʃt hɝ. ɪt sim ðəɾ ɪn ədɪʃən tə ðə ɹɛbəlz, ɛɡwin hæɾ ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə ædʒɹɛs ðə mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɑkjəpəns ə ðə taʊɝ. ʃi meɪɾ ə wiv tə ɛnhæns əɹ vɔɪs. nɑt tə bumɪŋ lɛvəlz, bʌɾ ɪnʌf tə lɛɾ əɹ bi hɝd boʊθ fɹəm bɪhaɪn ən bɪloʊ.

Egwene could see faces lining the lower windows. Aes Sedai and novices alike watched her. It seemed that in addition to the rebels, Egwene had an opportunity to address the majority of the remaining occupants of the Tower. She made a weave to enhance her voice. Not to booming levels, but enough to let her be heard both from behind and below.

"sɪstɝz," ʃi sɛd, "dɔɾɝz. aɪ hæv bɪn ɹeɪz pɹɑpɝli tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. boʊθ saɪdz ə ðɪs kɑnflɪkt əv tʃoʊzən mi. boʊθ fɑloʊd ðə pɹiskɹaɪb mɛθədz, ən boʊθ naʊ æksɛp mi əz ðɛɹ æmɪɝlɪn. ɪts taɪm tə dʒɔɪn təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn.

"Sisters," she said, "daughters. I have been raised properly to the Amyrlin Seat. Both sides of this conflict have chosen me. Both followed the prescribed methods, and both now accept me as their Amyrlin. It is time to join together again.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt pɹitɛn ðəɾ əɹ dɪvɪʒən dɪd nɑt teɪk pleɪs. wi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɑɹ səmtaɪmz tu iɡɝ tə fɝɡɛt ðoʊz fæks wi doʊnt wɑnə æknɑlɪdʒ. ðɪs wʌn kænɑt bi hɪɾən, nɑt fɹəm əs u lɪvd ɪt. wi wɝ dɪvaɪɾəd. wi nɪɹli keɪm tə wɔɹ wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ. wɪv dɪsɡɹeɪst aʊɝsɛlvz.

"I will not pretend that our division did not take place. We of the White Tower are sometimes too eager to forget those facts we don't want to acknowledge. This one cannot be hidden, not from us who lived it. We were divided. We nearly came to war with one another. We have disgraced ourselves.

"ju ɹɛbəlz bɪfɔɹ mi hæv dʌn sʌmθɪŋ tɛɹəbəl. juv ʃæɾɝd ðə taʊɝ ən ɹeɪzd ʌp ə ɹaɪvəl æmɪɝlɪn. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, tʃɹups əv bɪn mɑɹʃəl baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ lɛd ðoʊz tʃɹups. aɪ noʊ ʌv ðɪs ʃeɪm.

"You rebels before me have done something terrible. You have shattered the Tower and raised up a rival Amyrlin. For the first time, troops have been marshaled by Aes Sedai against Aes Sedai. I led those troops. I know of this shame.

"nɛsəsɛɹi əɹ nɑt, ɪts ə ʃeɪm. ən soʊ ɪts ðəɾ aɪ ɹikwaɪɝ jəɹ ædmɪʃən ʌv ɡɪlt. jə mʌs teɪk ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi fəɹ jəɹ kɹaɪmz, ivən ðoʊz pɝfɔɹmd ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɡʊd."

"Necessary or not, it is a shame. And so it is that I require your admission of guilt. You must take responsibility for your crimes, even those performed in the name of the greater good."

ʃi lʊk daʊn ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪloʊ. ɪf əɹ ækʃən ə fɔɹsɪŋ əm ɪndə ɹæŋks - ðən meɪkɪŋ əm weɪɾ əpɑn əɹ wɪl - hædn meɪɾ əm əwɛɹ ə hɝ æɾətud, ðən pɝhæps əɹ wɝdz wʊd.

She looked down at the Aes Sedai below. If her action of forcing them into ranks - then making them wait upon her will - hadn't made them aware of her attitude, then perhaps her words would.

"ju dɪd nɑt kʌm hɪɹ ɪn ɡlɔɹi," ɛɡwin sɛd tə ðɛm. "ju dɪd nɑt kʌm hɪɹ vɪktɔɹiəs. fəɹ ðəɹ ɪz noʊ vɪktɝi, ən cʊɾə bɪn noʊ vɪktɝi, wən sɪstɝ fɔt sɪstɝ ən wɔɹɾɝ daɪd tə wɔɹɾɝ." ʃi noʊɾəd sɪuən stændɪŋ nɪɹ ðə fɹʌn ə ðə ɹæŋks ən mɛɾ əɹ aɪz əkɹɔs ðə dɪstəns.

"You did not come here in glory," Egwene said to them. "You did not come here victorious. For there is no victory, and could have been no victory, when sister fought sister and Warder died to Warder." She noted Siuan standing near the front of the ranks and met her eyes across the distance.

lin wɑz ðɛɹ, tu, lʊkɪŋ dɪʃɛvəl fɹəm əɹ lɔŋ ɪmpɹɪzənmənt, bʌt stændɪŋ ɪɹɛkt.

Leane was there, too, looking disheveled from her long imprisonment, but standing erect.

"mɪsteɪks əv bɪn meɪɾ ɑn boʊθ saɪdz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ænd wɪl ɔl əv tə wɝk hɑɹd tə ɹɪpɛɹ wʌt wɪv dʌn. ɪts sɛd baɪ blæksmɪθs ðəɾ ə sɔɹd kən nɛvɝ bi hoʊl əɡɛn wʌns ɪts bɪn ʃæɾɝd. ɪt mʌs bi kəmplitli ɹɪfɔɝdʒd, ðə mɛɾəl mɛltəd daʊn tə slæɡ, ðən ɹiwɝkt ən ɹeɪ- fɔɹmd.

"Mistakes have been made on both sides," Egwene said. "And we will all have to work hard to repair what we have done. It is said by blacksmiths that a sword can never be whole again once it has been shattered. It must be completely reforged, the metal melted down to slag, then reworked and re- formed.

"ðiz nɛks fju mʌnθs wɪl bi əɹ ɹeɪ-fɔɹmɪŋ. wɪv bɪn bɹoʊkən, ðən tɔɹn daʊn nɪɹli tə ɹuts. ðə læs bæɾəl əpɹoʊtʃɪz, ən bɪfɔɹ ɪɾ ɝaɪvz, aɪ min tə si ðət wəɹ wʌns əɡɛn ə sɔɹd fɔɹdʒd wɪð stʃɹɛŋkθ, hoʊl ən ənbɹoʊkən! əl meɪk dɪmænz ə ju. ðəl bi hɑɹʃ. ðəl stʃɹɛtʃ jə tə ðə lɪməts ʌv wʌt jə θɪŋk jə kən bɛɹ. əl teɪk ðiz bɝn hoʊlz ən fɪl ðɛm!

"These next few months will be our re-forming. We have been broken, then torn down nearly to roots. The Last Battle approaches, and before it arrives, I mean to see that we are once again a sword forged with strength, whole and unbroken! I will make demands of you. They will be harsh. They will stretch you to the limits of what you think you can bear. I will take these burned holes and fill them!

əkɑmədeɪʃənz wɪl əv tə bi meɪd, fəɹ bɪtwin əs ðəɹ ɑɹ fɑɹ tu mɛni sɪɾɝz fəɹ ðə hɔl, nɑt tə mɛnʃən faɪv tu mɛni ədʒɑ hɛdz. səm ə jəl əv tə stɛp daʊn ən baʊ jʊɹsɛlvz ɪn hjumɪlɪɾi bɪfɔɹ ðoʊz jə dɪslaɪk.

Accommodations will have to be made, for between us there are far too many Sitters for the Hall, not to mention five too many Ajah heads. Some of you will have to step down and bow yourselves in humility before those you dislike.

"ðiz deɪz wɪl tɛs ju! əl fɔɹs jə tə wɝk wɪð ðoʊz jə sɔ əz ɛnəmiz dʒʌst aʊɝz əɡoʊ.

"These days will test you! I will force you to work with those you saw as enemies just hours ago.

jəl mɑɹtʃ əlɔŋsaɪd ðoʊz u spɝn ju, əɹ hɝt ju, əɹ heɪɾəd ju.

You will march alongside those who spurned you, or hurt you, or hated you.

"bʌt wəɹ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən əɹ wiknəsəz. ðə waɪt taʊɝ stænz, ən wi ʃæl stænd wɪð ɪt!

"But we are stronger than our weaknesses. The White Tower stands, and we shall stand with it!

wɪl bɪkʌm wʌn əɡɛn. wɪl bi ən əsɛmbli ðət teɪlz wɪl tɛl ʌv! wən aɪm fɪnɪʃt wɪð ju, ɪɾəl nɑt bi ɹɪɾən ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz wik. əɹ dɪvɪʒənz wɪl bi fɝɡɑɾən ɪn ðə feɪs ʌv əɹ vɪktɝiz. wɪl bi ɹɪmɛmbɝd nɑɾ əz ðə waɪt taʊɝ u tɝn əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf, bʌɾ əz ðə waɪt taʊɝ u stʊd stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə feɪs ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ðiz deɪz wɪl bi lɛdʒəndɛɹi!"

We will become one again. We will be an assembly that tales will tell of! When I am finished with you, it will not be written that the White Tower was weak. Our divisions will be forgotten in the face of our victories. We will be remembered not as the White Tower who turned against itself, but as the White Tower who stood strong in the face of the Shadow. These days will be legendary!"

tʃɪɹz bɝst aʊt, moʊsli fɹəm nɑvəsɪz ən soʊlʒɝz, əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ tu ɹɪzɝv fəɹ ðət sɔɹɾ ə bɪheɪvjɝ. dʒɛnɝəli. səm jʌŋɡɝ wʌnz dɪd kɔl aʊt, kɑɾ ʌp ɪn ðə moʊmənt. θæŋkfəli, ðoʊz tʃɪɹz keɪm fɹəm boʊθ saɪdz. ɛɡwin lɛɾ əm ɹɔɹ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən ɹeɪzd əɹ ɑɹmz, kwaɪəɾɪŋ ðɛm.

Cheers burst out, mostly from novices and soldiers, as the Aes Sedai were too reserved for that sort of behavior. Generally. Some younger ones did call out, caught up in the moment. Thankfully, those cheers came from both sides. Egwene let them roar for a moment, then raised her arms, quieting them.

"lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ fɔɹθ əkɹɔs ðə lænd!" ʃi ʃaʊɾəd. "lɛɾ ɪt bi spoʊkən ʌv, lɛɾ ɪt bi ɹɪlaɪɾ əpɑn, ən lɛɾ ɪt bi ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz hoʊl ən kəmplit. ən noʊ wʌn - mæn, wʊmən əɹ kɹieɪʃən ə ðə ʃædoʊ - wɪl si əs dɪvaɪɾəd əɡɛn!"

"Let it go forth across the land!" she shouted. "Let it be spoken of, let it be relied upon, and let it be remembered. The White Tower is whole and complete. And no one - man, woman or creation of the Shadow - will see us divided again!"

ðə tʃɪɹz wɝ nɪɹli dɛfənɪŋ ðɪs taɪm, ən sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ dʒɔɪn ɪn. ɛɡwin loʊɝɾ əɹ hænz.

The cheers were nearly deafening this time, and surprisingly, more Aes Sedai joined in. Egwene lowered her hands.

ʃi hoʊp ðeɪ wəd stɪl tʃɪɹ əɹ ɪn ðə mʌnθs tə kʌm. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv wɝk tə bi dʌn.

She hoped they would still cheer her in the months to come. There was a great deal of work to be done.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɛvən

CHAPTER 47

ðə wʌn i lɔst ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz ɹumz ɪmiɾiətli. ðə feɪl miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz hæd lɛft ɪm filɪŋ ənhɪnʒd. nɑt kəz ə ðɛɹ tʃɹɪki ətɛmp tə pʊl ɪm ɪndə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ - ðət wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd. pipəl ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə kəntʃɹoʊl ən mənɪpjəleɪt hɪm. ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɝ noʊ dɪfɹənt.

The One He Lost Rand did not return to his rooms immediately. The failed meeting with the Borderlanders had left him feeling unhinged. Not because of their tricky attempt to pull him into Far Madding - that was frustrating, but it was not unexpected. People always tried to control and manipulate him. The Borderlanders were no different.

noʊ, ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ðət hæɾ ənsɛɾəld hɪm, sʌmθɪŋ i kʊdn kwaɪt dɪfaɪn. ən soʊ hi stɔk θɹu ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ, tu il meɪɾənz tʃɹeɪlɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, hɪz pɹɛzəns stɑɹtlɪŋ sɝvəns ən ənɝvɪŋ dɪfɛndɝz.

No, it was something else that had unsettled him, something he couldn't quite define. And so he stalked through the Stone of Tear, two Aiel Maidens trailing behind him, his presence startling servants and unnerving Defenders.

ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz twɪstəɾ ən tɝnd. ðə wɔlz - wɛɹ ʌnədɔɹn baɪ tæpəstʃɹi - wɝ ðə kʌlɝ ʌv wɛt sænd, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛni ɹɑk ɹænd nu, eɪliən ən stʃɹeɪnʒ; itʃ smuð spæn ə ɹimaɪndɝ ðət ðɪs pleɪs wɑz nɑt nætʃɹəl.

The corridors twisted and turned. The walls - where unadorned by tapestry - were the color of wet sand, but they were far stronger than any rock Rand knew, alien and strange; each smooth span a reminder that this place was not natural.

ɹænd fɛl ðə seɪm weɪ. hi hæd ðə fɔɹm ʌv ə hjumən. ɪndid, hi hæd ðə mænɝɪzəmz ən hɪstɝi ʌv wʌn. bʌɾ i wɑz ə θɪŋ ðət noʊ hjumən - nɑɾ ivən i hɪmsɛlf - kəɾ ʌndɝstænd. ə fɪɡjɝ ə lɛdʒənd, ə kɹieɪʃən ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, əz ənnætʃɹəl əz ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil əɹ ə fɹæɡmən ə kwəndɪlɝ. ðeɪ dʒɹɛst ɪm ʌp laɪk ə kɪŋ, dʒʌst əz ðeɪ dʒɹɛs ðiz kɔɹɪɾɝz wɪð tæsɛld ɡoʊld ən ɹɛd ɹʌɡz. dʒʌst əz ðeɪ hʌŋ ðə wɔlz wɪð ðoʊz tæpəstʃɹiz, itʃ wʌn dɪpɪktɪŋ ə feɪməs tɛɹən dʒɛnɝəl. ðoʊz dɛkɝeɪʃənz wɝ ɪntɛndəd fəɹ bjuɾi, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɔlsoʊ ɪntɛndəd tə əbskjʊɹ. ðə pætʃəz ə neɪkəd wɔl haɪlaɪɾɪd haʊ eɪliən ðə pleɪs wɑz. ɹʌɡz ən tæpəstʃɹiz meɪɾ ɪɾ ɔl fil mɔɹ . . . hjumən. dʒʌst əz ɡɪvɪŋ ɹænd ə kɹaʊn ən ə faɪn koʊɾ əlaʊɾ əm tə æksɛp hɪm. kɪŋz wɝ səpoʊz tə bi ə lɪɾəl dɪfɹənt. nɛvɝ maɪn ɪz mʌtʃ mɔɹ eɪliən neɪtʃɝ, hɪɾən bɪniθ ðə kɹaʊn. nɛvɝ maɪn ɪz hɑɹɾ ʌv ə mæn lɔŋ dɛd, hɪz ʃoʊldɝz kɹieɪɾəd tə bɛɹ ðə weɪɾ ə pɹɑfəsi, hɪz soʊl kɹʌʃt baɪ ðə nidz, wɑns ən hoʊps ʌv ə mɪljən pipəl.

Rand felt the same way. He had the form of a human. Indeed, he had the mannerisms and history of one. But he was a thing that no human - not even he himself - could understand. A figure of legend, a creation of the One Power, as unnatural as a ter'angreal or a fragment of cuendillar. They dressed him up like a king, just as they dressed these corridors with tasseled gold and red rugs. Just as they hung the walls with those tapestries, each one depicting a famous Tairen general. Those decorations were intended for beauty, but they were also intended to obscure. The patches of naked wall highlighted how alien the place was. Rugs and tapestries made it all feel more . . . human. Just as giving Rand a crown and a fine coat allowed them to accept him. Kings were supposed to be a little different. Never mind his much more alien nature, hidden beneath the crown. Never mind his heart of a man long dead, his shoulders created to bear the weight of prophecy, his soul crushed by the needs, wants and hopes of a million people.

tu hænz. wʌn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ, ði ʌðɝ tə seɪv. wɪtʃ hæɾ i lɔst?

Two hands. One to destroy, the other to save. Which had he lost?

ɪt wɑz izi tə ɡoʊ əstʃɹeɪ ɪn ðə stoʊn. lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə pæɾɝn hæd bɪɡʌn tə ənɹævəl, ðiz twɪstɪŋ kɔɹɪɾɝz ə bɹaʊn ɹɑk hæd bɪn mɪsliɾɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ dɪzaɪn tə bɪfʌɾəl ətækɝz.

It was easy to go astray in the Stone. Long before the Pattern had begun to unravel, these twisting corridors of brown rock had been misleading. They were designed to befuddle attackers.

ɪntɝsɛkʃənz keɪm ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli; ðəɹ wɝ fju lændmɑɹks, ən ði ɪnɝ kɔɹɪɾɝz ə ðə kip dɪdn əv wɪndoʊz. ði il sɛd ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɪmpɹɛst wɪð haʊ dɪfəkəlt ɪt hæd bɪn tə siz ðə stoʊn. ɪt hædn bɪn ðə dɪfɛndɝz u hæɾ ɪmpɹɛs ðɛm, bʌt ðə ʃɪɹ skoʊp ən leɪaʊɾ ə ðə mɑnstʃɹəs bɪldɪŋ.

Intersections came unexpectedly; there were few landmarks, and the inner corridors of the keep didn't have windows. The Aiel said they had been impressed with how difficult it had been to seize the Stone. It hadn't been the Defenders who had impressed them, but the sheer scope and layout of the monstrous building.

fɔɹtʃənətli, ɹænd hæd noʊ pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɡoʊl. hi sɪmpli wɑntəd tə wɔk.

Fortunately, Rand had no particular goal. He simply wanted to walk.

hi hæɾ æksɛptɪd wʌɾ i niɾəd tə bi. waɪ wɑz i soʊ bɑðɝd baɪ ɪt, ðɛn? ə vɔɪs dip daʊn  - wʌn nɑɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ ɪn ɪz hɑɹt - hæd bɪɡʌn tə dɪsəɡɹi wɪð wʌɾ i dɪd. ɪt wɑz nɑt laʊɾ əɹ vaɪələn laɪk luz θɝɪnz; ɪt dʒʌst wɪspɝd, laɪk ə fɝɡɑɾən ɪtʃ. sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ. sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ. . . .

He had accepted what he needed to be. Why was he so bothered by it, then? A voice deep down  - one not in his head, but in his heart - had begun to disagree with what he did. It was not loud or violent like Lews Therin's; it just whispered, like a forgotten itch. Something is wrong. Something is wrong. . . .

noʊ! hi θɔt. aɪ mʌs bi stʃɹɔŋ. aɪ hæv faɪnəli bɪkʌm wʌɾ aɪ mʌs bi!

No! he thought. I must be strong. I have finally become what I must be!

hi stɑpt ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, tiθ ɡɹɪɾɪd. ɪn ɪz dip koʊt pɑkət, hi kæɹid ði æksɛs ki. hi fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪt, ɪts kɑntʊɹz koʊld ən smuð. hi dɪdn dɛɹ liv ɪt tə ðə kɛɹ ʌv ə sɝvənt, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ tʃɹʌstɪd.

He stopped in the corridor, teeth gritted. In his deep coat pocket, he carried the access key. He fingered it, its contours cold and smooth. He didn't dare leave it to the care of a servant, no matter how trusted.

hʊɹɪn, hi ɹilaɪzd. ðæts wʌɾ ɪz bɑðɝɪŋ mi. siɪŋ hʊɹɪn.

Hurin, he realized. That's what is bothering me. Seeing Hurin.

hi ɹɪzumd wɔkɪŋ, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ɪz bæk. hi hæd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ - əɹ ət list əpɪɹ stʃɹɔŋ - əɾ ɔl taɪmz.

He resumed walking, straightening his back. He had to be strong - or at least appear strong - at all times.

hʊɹɪn wɑz ə ɹɛlɪk fɹəm ən ɝliɝ laɪf. deɪz wən mæt hæd stɪl mɑkt ɹændz koʊts, deɪz wən ɹænd hæd hoʊp ðət hid mɛɹi ɛɡwin ən sʌmhaʊ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. hi hæd tʃɹævəld wɪð hʊɹɪn ən lɔɪəl, dɪtɝmən tə stɑp feɪn ən ɡɛt bæk mæts dæɡɝ, tə pɹuv ðəɾ i wɑz ə fɹɛnd. ðət hæd bɪn ə mʌtʃ sɪmpəlɝ taɪm, ɔlðoʊ ɹænd hædnt noʊn ɪt. hiɾ əv wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɛniθɪŋ kəd ɡɹoʊ mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ðən θɪŋkɪŋ ɪz fɹɛnz heɪɾəd hɪm.

Hurin was a relic from an earlier life. Days when Mat had still mocked Rand's coats, days when Rand had hoped that he'd marry Egwene and somehow return to the Two Rivers. He had traveled with Hurin and Loial, determined to stop Fain and get back Mat's dagger, to prove that he was a friend. That had been a much simpler time, although Rand hadn't known it. He'd have wondered if anything could grow more complicated than thinking his friends hated him.

ðə kʌlɝz ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ɪz vɪʒən. pɛɹɪn wɔkɪŋ θɹu ə dɑɹk kæmp, ðət stoʊn sɔɹd lumɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ əbʌv hɪm. ðə vɪʒən tʃeɪnʒd tə mæt, hu wɑz stɪl ɪn ðət sɪɾi. ɪt wɑz keɪɛmlɪn? waɪ kəɾ i bi nɪɹ ɪleɪn, wən ɹænd hæd tə ɹɪmeɪn soʊ fɑɹ əweɪ? hi kəd bɛɹli fil əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz θɹu ðə bɑnd. hi mɪst əɹ soʊ. wʌns ðeɪ hæd stoʊlən kɪsəz fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə hɔlz ə ðɪs vɛɹi fɔɹtʃɹəs.

The colors shifted in his vision. Perrin walking through a dark camp, that stone sword looming in the air above him. The vision changed to Mat, who was still in that city. It was Caemlyn? Why could he be near Elayne, when Rand had to remain so far away? He could barely feel her emotions through the bond. He missed her so. Once they had stolen kisses from one another in the halls of this very fortress.

noʊ, hi θɔt. aɪm stʃɹɔŋ. lɔŋɪŋ wɑz ən ɪmoʊʃən i mʌsnt fil. nɔstælʒə ɡɑɾ ɪm noʊwɛɹ.

No, he thought. I am strong. Longing was an emotion he mustn't feel. Nostalgia got him nowhere.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə bænɪʃ boʊθ, dʌkɪŋ ɪndə ə stɛɹwɛl ən muvɪŋ daʊn ðə stɛps, wɝkɪŋ ɪz bɑɾi, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɪz bɹɛθ kʌm ɪn ɡæsps.

He tried to banish both, ducking into a stairwell and moving down the steps, working his body, trying to make his breath come in gasps.

də wi ɹʌn fɹəm ðə pæst, ðɛn? luz θɝɪn æsk sɔfli. jɛs. ðəɾ ɪz wɛl. bɛɾɝ tə ɹʌn ðən tə feɪs ɪt.

Do we run from the past, then? Lews Therin asked softly. Yes. That is well. Better to run than to face it.

ɹændz taɪm wɪð hʊɹɪn hæɾ ɛndəɾ ət fɑlm. ðoʊz deɪz wɝ ɪndɪstɪŋkt ɪn ɪz maɪnd. ðə tʃeɪnʒəz ðət hæd kʌm əpɑn ɪm ðən - ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ i hæd tə kɪl, ðəɾ i kəd nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə laɪf i hæd lʌvd - wɝ θɪŋz i kəd nɑt dwɛl ɑn. hid hɛɾəd aʊt təwɔɹd tɛɹ, ɔlmoʊs dɪlɪɹiəs, sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ɪz fɹɛnz, siɪŋ ɪʃəml ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz.

Rand's time with Hurin had ended at Falme. Those days were indistinct in his mind. The changes that had come upon him then - realizing that he had to kill, that he could never return to the life he had loved - were things he could not dwell on. He'd headed out toward Tear, almost delirious, separated from his friends, seeing Ishamael in his dreams.

ðət læst wʌn wɑz hæpənɪŋ əɡɛn.

That last one was happening again.

ɹænd bɝst aʊɾ ɑntu wʌn ə ðə loʊɝ flɔɹz ə ðə kip, bɹiðɪŋ dipli. hɪz meɪɾənz fɑloʊd hɪm, nɑt wɪndɪd. hi stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ ən ɪndə ə mæsɪv tʃeɪmbɝ wɪð ɹoʊz ə pɪlɝz, staʊɾ ən bɹɔd, waɪɾɝ ðən ə mæn kəd ɹæp ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊnd. ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn. sɛvɹəl dɪfɛndɝz keɪm tə ətɛnʃən ən səluɾəd əz ɹænd pæs ðɛm.

Rand burst out onto one of the lower floors of the keep, breathing deeply. His Maidens followed him, not winded. He strode down the hallway and into a massive chamber with rows of pillars, stout and broad, wider than a man could wrap his arms around. The Heart of the Stone. Several Defenders came to attention and saluted as Rand passed them.

hi wɔk tə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə hɑɹt. wʌns, kælændɝ hæd hʌŋ hɪɹ, ɡlɪsnɪŋ wɪð laɪt. ðə kɹɪstəl sɔɹd wɑz naʊ ɪn kædzueɪnz pəzɛʃən. hoʊpfəli, ʃi hædn bʌŋɡəl ðəɾ ən lɔst ɪɾ əz ʃi hæd ðə meɪl æɾəm. ɹænd dɪdn ɹɪli kɛɹ. kælændɝ wɑz ɪnfɪɹiɝ; tə juz ɪt, ə mæn hæd tə səbdʒɛk hɪmsɛlf tə ðə wɪl ʌv ə wʊmən. bɪsaɪdz, ɪt wɑz paʊɝfəl, bʌt nɑt nɪɹli əz paʊɝfəl əz ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl. ði æksɛs ki wɑz ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ tul. ɹænd stʃɹoʊkt ɪt kwaɪətli, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə pleɪs wɛɹ kælændɝ hæd wʌns hʌŋ.

He walked to the center of the Heart. Once, Callandor had hung here, glistening with light. The crystal sword was now in Cadsuane's possession. Hopefully, she hadn't bungled that and lost it as she had the male a'dam. Rand didn't really care. Callandor was inferior; to use it, a man had to subject himself to the will of a woman. Besides, it was powerful, but not nearly as powerful as the Choedan Kal. The access key was a much better tool. Rand stroked it quietly, regarding the place where Callandor had once hung.

ðɪs hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɑðɝd hɪm. kælændɝ wɑz ðə wɛpən spoʊkən ʌv ɪn ðə pɹɑfəsiz. ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl sɛd ðət ðə stoʊn wəd nɑt fɔl əntɪl kælændɝ wɑz wildɪd baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. tə səm skɑlɝz, ðət pæsədʒ hæɾ ɪmplaɪd ðət ðə sɔɹd wəd nɛvɝ bi wildɪd. bʌt ðə pɹɑfəsiz dɪd nɑt wɝk ðət weɪ - ðeɪ wɝ meɪd tə bi fʊlfɪld.

This had always bothered him. Callandor was the weapon spoken of in the prophecies. The Karaethon Cycle said that the Stone would not fall until Callandor was wielded by the Dragon Reborn. To some scholars, that passage had implied that the sword would never be wielded. But the prophecies did not work that way - they were made to be fulfilled.

ɹænd hæd stʌɾid ðə kæɹæəθən pɹɑfəsi. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, tizɪŋ aʊɾ ɪts minɪŋ wɑz laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əntaɪ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɑɹdz ə tæŋɡəld ɹoʊp. wɪð wʌn hænd.

Rand had studied the Karaethon Prophecy. Unfortunately, teasing out its meaning was like trying to untie a hundred yards of tangled rope. With one hand.

teɪkɪŋ ðə sɔɹd ðət kænɑt bi tʌtʃt wɑz wʌn ə ðə fɝs meɪdʒɝ pɹɑfəsiz ðəɾ i hæd fʊlfɪld. bʌt wɑz ɪz teɪkɪŋ ə kælændɝ ə minɪŋləs saɪn, əɹ wɑz ɪɾ ə stɛp? ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðə pɹɑfəsi, bʌt fju æsk ðə kwɛstʃən ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪnɛvəɾəbəl. waɪ? waɪ dɪd ɹænd əv tə teɪk ʌp ðə sɔɹd? wɑz ɪt tə bi juzd ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl?

Taking the Sword That Cannot Be Touched was one of the first major prophecies that he had fulfilled. But was his taking of Callandor a meaningless sign, or was it a step? Everyone knew the prophecy, but few asked the question that should have been inevitable. Why? Why did Rand have to take up the sword? Was it to be used in the Last Battle?

ðə sɔɹd wɑz ɪnfɪɹiɝ əz ə sɑŋɡɹil, ən i daʊɾɪd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɪntɛndəd tə bi juz sɪmpli əz ə sɔɹd. waɪ dɪd ðə pɹɑfəsiz nɑt spik ə ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl? hi hæd juz ðoʊz tə klɛnz ðə teɪnt. ði æksɛs ki ɡeɪv ɹænd paʊɝ wɛl bɪɑnd wʌt kælændɝ kəd pɹəvaɪd, ən ðət paʊɝ keɪm wɪð noʊ stʃɹɪŋz. ðə stætʃuɛt wɑz fɹiɾəm, bʌt kælændɝ wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ bɑks. jɛt tɔk ə ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl ən ðɛɹ kiz wɑz æbsən fɹəm ðə pɹɑfəsiz.

The sword was inferior as a sa'angreal, and he doubted that it was intended to be used simply as a sword. Why did the prophecies not speak of the Choedan Kal? He had used those to cleanse the taint. The access key gave Rand power well beyond what Callandor could provide, and that power came with no strings. The statuette was freedom, but Callandor was just another box. Yet talk of the Choedan Kal and their keys was absent from the prophecies.

ɹænd faʊn ðət fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ, fəɹ ðə pɹɑfəsiz wɝ - ɪn ə weɪ - ðə ɡɹændəst ən moʊst staɪflɪŋ bɑks ə ðɛm ɔl. hi wɑz tʃɹæpt ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðɛm. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðeɪ wəd sʌfəkeɪt hɪm.

Rand found that frustrating, for the prophecies were - in a way - the grandest and most stifling box of them all. He was trapped inside of them. Eventually, they would suffocate him.

aɪ toʊld əm . . . luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd.

I told them . . . Lews Therin whispered.

toʊld əm wʌt? ɹænd dɪmændəd.

Told them what? Rand demanded.

ðət ðə plæn wəd nɑt wɝk, luz θɝɪn sɛd, vɔɪs vɛɹi sɑft. ðət bɹut fɔɹs wəd nɑt kənteɪn hɪm. ðeɪ kɔl maɪ plæn bɹæʃ, bʌt ðiz wɛpənz ðeɪ kɹieɪɾəd, ðeɪ wɝ tu deɪnʒɝəs.

That the plan would not work, Lews Therin said, voice very soft. That brute force would not contain him. They called my plan brash, but these weapons they created, they were too dangerous.

tu fɹaɪɾənɪŋ. noʊ mæn ʃəd hoʊl sətʃ paʊɝ . . .

Too frightening. No man should hold such Power . . .

ɹænd stʃɹʌɡəld wɪð ðə θɔts, ðə vɔɪs, ðə mɛmɹiz. hi kʊdn ɹikɔl mʌtʃ əɾ ɔl ə luz θɝɪnz plæn tə sil ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl - hæd ðeɪ bɪn bɪl fəɹ ðət pɝpəs?

Rand struggled with the thoughts, the voice, the memories. He couldn't recall much at all of Lews Therin's plan to Seal the Dark One's prison. The Choedan Kal - had they been built for that purpose?

wɑz ðət ði ænsɝ? hæd luz θɝɪn meɪd ðə ɹɔŋ tʃɔɪs? waɪ, ðɛn, wɑz ðəɹ noʊ mɛnʃən ə ðɛm ɪn ðə pɹɑfəsiz?

Was that the answer? Had Lews Therin made the wrong choice? Why, then, was there no mention of them in the prophecies?

ɹænd tɝn tə liv ði ɛmpti tʃeɪmbɝ. "ɡɑɹd ðɪs pleɪs noʊ mɔɹ," hi sɛd tə ðə dɪfɛndɝz.

Rand turned to leave the empty chamber. "Guard this place no more," he said to the Defenders.

"ðɛɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ hɪɹ ʌv wɝθ. aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf ðəɹ ɛvɝ wɑz."

"There is nothing here of worth. I'm not sure if there ever was."

ðə mɛn lʊkt ʃɑkt, mɔɹɾəfaɪd, laɪk tʃɪlʒɹən dʒʌs tʃæstaɪz baɪ ə bɪlʌv fɑðɝ. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə wɔɹ kʌmɪŋ, ən i wʊdn liv soʊlʒɝz bɪhaɪn tə dɪfɛn ən ɛmpti ɹum.

The men looked shocked, mortified, like children just chastised by a beloved father. But there was a war coming, and he wouldn't leave soldiers behind to defend an empty room.

ɹænd ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ ən stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ə hɔlweɪ. kælændɝ. wɛɹ hæd kædzueɪn hɪɾən ɪt? hi nu ʃid teɪkən ɹumz ɪn ðə stoʊn, əɡɛn pʊʃɪŋ ðə lɪməts ə hɪz ɛɡzaɪl. hi wəɾ əv tə də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt. kæst əɹ fɹəm ðə stoʊn, pɝhæps. hi hɝiɾ ʌp ðə stoʊn stɛps, ðən lɛf ðə stɛɹwɛl ɑn ə ɹændəm flɔɹ, kəntɪnjuɪŋ tə muv. sɪɾɪŋ naʊ wəd dʒɹaɪv ɪm mæd.

Rand gritted his teeth and strode into a hallway. Callandor. Where had Cadsuane hidden it? He knew she'd taken rooms in the Stone, again pushing the limits of his exile. He would have to do something about that. Cast her from the Stone, perhaps. He hurried up the stone steps, then left the stairwell on a random floor, continuing to move. Sitting now would drive him mad.

hi wɝk soʊ hɑɹd tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ taɪd wɪð stʃɹɪŋz, bʌɾ ət ði ɛn ə ðə deɪ, ðə pɹɑfəsiz wəd si ðəɾ i dɪd wʌɾ i wɑz səpoʊz tə. ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ mənɪpjəleɪɾɪv, mɔɹ diviəs, ðən ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ.

He worked so hard to keep from being tied with strings, but at the end of the day, the prophecies would see that he did what he was supposed to. They were more manipulative, more devious, than any Aes Sedai.

hɪz æŋɡɝ wɛld ʌp ɪnsaɪd hɪm, ɹeɪdʒɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪts kənstʃɹeɪns. ðə kwaɪət vɔɪs dip wɪðɪn ʃɪvɝɾ ət ðə tɛmpəst. ɹænd lin ɪz lɛft ɑɹm əɡɛns ðə wɔl, boʊɪŋ ɪz hɛd, tiθ ɡɹɪɾɪd.

His anger welled up inside him, raging against its constraints. The quiet voice deep within shivered at the tempest. Rand leaned his left arm against the wall, bowing his head, teeth gritted.

"aɪ wɪl bi stʃɹɔŋ," hi wɪspɝd. ən jɛt, ði æŋɡɝ wəd nɑt ɡoʊ əweɪ. ən waɪ ʃəɾ ɪt? ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz dɪfaɪd hɪm. ðə sintʃæn dɪfaɪd hɪm. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹitɛndəd tə oʊbeɪ hɪm, jɛt daɪnd wɪð kædzueɪn bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk ən dænst əɾ əɹ kəmænd.

"I will be strong," he whispered. And yet, the anger would not go away. And why should it? The Borderlanders defied him. The Seanchan defied him. The Aes Sedai pretended to obey him, yet dined with Cadsuane behind his back and danced at her command.

kædzueɪn dɪfaɪɾ ɪm moʊst ʌv ɔl. steɪɪŋ ɹaɪt nɪɹ hɪm, flaʊɾɪŋ ɪz wɝdz ə kəmæn ən twɪstɪŋ ɪz ɪntɛntʃənz. hi pʊld aʊt ði æksɛs ki, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ɪt. ðə læs bæɾəl lumd, ən i spɛnt wʌt lɪɾəl taɪm i hæd ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə miɾɪŋz wɪð pipəl u ɪnsʌltɪd hɪm. ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz ənɹævəlɪŋ ðə pæɾɝn mɔɹ itʃ deɪ, ən ðoʊz swɔɹn tə pɹətɛk ðə bɔɹɾɝz wɝ haɪɾɪŋ ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ.

Cadsuane defied him most of all. Staying right near him, flouting his words of command and twisting his intentions. He pulled out the access key, fingering it. The Last Battle loomed, and he spent what little time he had riding to meetings with people who insulted him. The Dark One was unraveling the Pattern more each day, and those sworn to protect the borders were hiding in Far Madding.

hi ɡlænst ɝaʊnd, bɹiðɪŋ dipli. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ hɔlweɪ sim fəmɪljɝ.

He glanced around, breathing deeply. Something about this particular hallway seemed familiar.

hi wɑzn sɝɾən waɪ; ɪt lʊk laɪk ɔl ə ði ʌðɝz. ɹʌɡz ʌv ɡoʊld ən ɹɛd. ən ɪntɝsɛkʃən ə hɔlweɪz əhɛd.

He wasn't certain why; it looked like all of the others. Rugs of gold and red. An intersection of hallways ahead.

meɪbi hi ʃʊdn əv lɛt ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz sɝvaɪv ðɛɹ dɪfaɪəns. pɝhæps i ʃəd ɡoʊ bæk ən si ðət ðeɪ lɝn tə fɪɹ hɪm. bʌt noʊ. hi dɪdnt nid ðɛm. hi kəd liv əm fəɹ ðə sintʃæn. ðət bɔɹɾɝləndɝ ɑɹmi wəd sɝv tə sloʊ hɪz ɛnəmiz hɪɹ ɪn ðə saʊθ. pɝhæps ðət wəd kip ðə sintʃæn fɹəm ɪz flæŋks waɪl i dɛlt wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

Maybe he shouldn't have let the Borderlanders survive their defiance. Perhaps he should go back and see that they learned to fear him. But no. He didn't need them. He could leave them for the Seanchan. That Borderlander army would serve to slow his enemies here in the south. Perhaps that would keep the Seanchan from his flanks while he dealt with the Dark One.

bʌt . . . wɑz ðɛɹ, pɝhæps, ə weɪ tə stɑp ðə sintʃæn fəɹ ɡʊd? hi lʊk daʊn ət ði æksɛs ki. wʌns i hæd tʃɹaɪd tə juz kælændɝ tə faɪt ðə fɔɹən ɪnveɪɾɝz. hi hædn jɛɾ ʌndɝstʊd waɪ ðə sɔɹd wɑz soʊ dɪfəkəl tə kəntʃɹoʊl: oʊnli æftɝ ɪz dɪzæstʃɹəs əsɔl hæd kædzueɪn ɪkspleɪnd wʌt ʃi nu əbaʊɾ ɪt. ɹænd niɾəd tə bi ɪn ə sɝkəl wɪð tu wɪmən bɪfɔɹ i kəd seɪfli wil ðə sɔɹd ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə sɔɹd.

But . . . was there, perhaps, a way to stop the Seanchan for good? He looked down at the access key. Once he had tried to use Callandor to fight the foreign invaders. He hadn't yet understood why the sword was so difficult to control: only after his disastrous assault had Cadsuane explained what she knew about it. Rand needed to be in a circle with two women before he could safely wield the sword that was not a sword.

ðət hæd bɪn ɪz fɝs meɪdʒɝ feɪljɝ əz ə kəmændɝ.

That had been his first major failure as a commander.

bʌɾ i hæɾ ə bɛɾɝ tul naʊ. ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl tul ɛvɝ kɹieɪɾəd; ʃʊɹli noʊ hjumən kəd hoʊl mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən i hæd wən klɛnzɪŋ seɪɾɪn. bɝnɪŋ ɡɹeɪndəl ən nætʃɹɪnz bæɹoʊ əweɪ hæd ɹikwaɪɝɾ oʊnli ə fɹækʃən ʌv wʌt ɹænd kəd sʌmən.

But he had a better tool now. The most powerful tool ever created; surely no human could hold more of the One Power than he had when cleansing saidin. Burning Graendal and Natrin's Barrow away had required only a fraction of what Rand could summon.

ɪf i tɝn ðəɾ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn, ðən i kəd ɡoʊ tə ðə læs bæɾəl wɪð kɑnfəɾəns, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝiɾ əbaʊt wʌt wɑz kɹipɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi hæd ɡɪvən əm ðɛɹ tʃæns. sɛvɹəl tʃænsəz. hi hæd wɔɹn kædzueɪn, toʊld əɹ ðət hid baɪn ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz tə hɪm.

If he turned that against the Seanchan, then he could go to the Last Battle with confidence, no longer worried about what was creeping along behind him. He had given them their chance. Several chances. He had warned Cadsuane, told her that he'd bind the Daughter of the Nine Moons to him.

wʌn weɪ . . . əɹ ənʌðɝ.

One way . . . or another.

ɪt wəd nɑt teɪk lɔŋ.

It would not take long.

ðɛɹ, luz θɝɪn sɛd. wi stʊd ðɛɹ.

There, Lews Therin said. We stood there.

ɹænd fɹaʊnd. wʌt wɑz ðə mædmæn bæbəlɪŋ əbaʊt? hi ɡlænst ɝaʊnd. ðə waɪd hɔlweɪz flɔɹ wɑz taɪld ɪn ɹɛɾ ən blæk pæɾɝnz. ə fju tæpəstʃɹiz flʌɾɝd ɑn ðə wɔlz. wɪð ʃɑk, ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðət sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm dɪpɪktəd hɪm, teɪkɪŋ ðə stoʊn, hoʊldɪŋ kælændɝ, kɪlɪŋ tʃɹɑləks.

Rand frowned. What was the madman babbling about? He glanced around. The wide hallway's floor was tiled in red and black patterns. A few tapestries fluttered on the walls. With shock, Rand realized that several of them depicted him, taking the Stone, holding Callandor, killing Trollocs.

faɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn wɑzn əɹ fɝs feɪljɝ, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. noʊ, əɹ fɝs feɪljɝ hæpən hɪɹ. ɪn ðɪs hɔlweɪ.

Fighting the Seanchan wasn't our first failure, Lews Therin whispered. No, our first failure happened here. In this hallway.

ɪɡzɔstəd, fɑloʊɪŋ ðə bæɾəl wɪð ðə tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl. hɪz saɪd θɹɑbɪŋ. ðə stoʊn stɪl ɹɪŋɪŋ wɪð ðə kɹaɪz ə ðə wundəd. filɪŋ i kəd də ɛniθɪŋ. ɛniθɪŋ.

Exhausted, following the battle with the Trollocs and Myrddraal. His side throbbing. The Stone still ringing with the cries of the wounded. Feeling he could do anything. Anything.

stændɪŋ əbʌv ðə kɔɹps ʌv ə jʌŋ ɡɝl. dʒʌst ə tʃaɪld. kælændɝ ɡloʊɪŋ ɪn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ðə bɑɾi sʌɾənli dʒɝkt.

Standing above the corpse of a young girl. Just a child. Callandor glowing in his fingers. The body suddenly jerked.

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd stɑp hɪm. bɹɪŋɪŋ laɪf tə ðə dɛd wɑz bɪɑn hɪm, ʃid sɛd.

Moiraine had stopped him. Bringing life to the dead was beyond him, she'd said.

haʊ aɪ wɪʃ ʃi wɑz stɪl hɪɹ, ɹænd θɔt. hi hæɾ ɔfən bɪn fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd wɪð hɝ, bʌt ʃi -  mɔɹ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls - hæd sim tə ɡɹæsp dʒʌst wʌɾ ɪt wɑz i wɑz ɪkspɛktəd tə du. ʃid meɪɾ ɪm mɔɹ wɪlɪŋ tə də ɪt, ivən wən hid bɪn æŋɡɹi wɪð hɝ.

How I wish she was still here, Rand thought. He had often been frustrated with her, but she -  more than anyone else - had seemed to grasp just what it was he was expected to do. She'd made him more willing to do it, even when he'd been angry with her.

hi tɝn əweɪ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. hi kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ laɪf tə ðoʊz u wɝ dɛd. bʌɾ i wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət bɹɪŋɪŋ dɛθ tə ðoʊz u lɪvd. "ɡæðɝ jəɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz," ɹænd kɔld oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə hɪz il ɡɑɹdz. "wi ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə bæɾəl."

He turned away. Moiraine had been right. He could not bring life to those who were dead. But he was very good at bringing death to those who lived. "Gather your spear-sisters," Rand called over his shoulder to his Aiel guards. "We are going to battle."

"naʊ?" wʌn ə ðɛm æskt. "ɪɾ ɪz naɪtfɔl!"

"Now?" one of them asked. "It is nightfall!"

hæv aɪ bɪn wɔkɪŋ ðət lɔŋ? ɹænd θɔt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz. "jɛs," hi sɛd. "ðə dɑɹknəs woʊn mæɾɝ; aɪ ʃæl kɹieɪt laɪɾ ɪnʌf." hi fɪŋɡɝd ði æksɛs ki, filɪŋ ə θɹɪl ən ə hɔɹɝ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. hi hæd dʒɹɪvən ðə sintʃæn bæk ɪndə ði oʊʃən wʌns. hi wəd də soʊ əɡɛn. əloʊn.

Have I been walking that long? Rand thought with surprise. "Yes," he said. "The darkness won't matter; I shall create light enough." He fingered the access key, feeling a thrill and a horror at the same time. He had driven the Seanchan back into the ocean once. He would do so again. Alone.

jɛs, hi wəd dʒɹaɪv əm bæk - ət list, ðə wʌnz i lɛft əlaɪv.

Yes, he would drive them back - at least, the ones he left alive.

"ɡoʊ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd ət ðə meɪɾənz. ðeɪ lɛf hɪm, ləpɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. wʌt hæd hæpən tə hɪz kəntʃɹoʊl? ði aɪs hæd ɡɹoʊn θɪn leɪtli.

"Go!" he shouted at the Maidens. They left him, loping down the hallway. What had happened to his control? The ice had grown thin lately.

hi wɔk bæk tə ðə stɛɹweɪ ən klaɪmd ə fju flaɪts ʌp təwɔɹɾ ɪz ɹumz. ðə sintʃæn wəd noʊ hɪz fjʊɹi. ðeɪ dɛɹd tə pɹəvoʊk ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? hi ɔfɝɾ əm pis, ən ðeɪ læft ət hɪm?

He walked back to the stairway and climbed a few flights up toward his rooms. The Seanchan would know his fury. They dared to provoke the Dragon Reborn? He offered them peace, and they laughed at him?

hi θɹu oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə hɪz ɹumz, saɪlənsɪŋ ði iɡɝ dɪfɛndɝz ɑn ɡɑɹɾ aʊtsaɪd wɪð ə ʃɑɹpli əpɹeɪz hænd. hi wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ðə mud fəɹ ðɛɹ pɹæɾəl.

He threw open the door to his rooms, silencing the eager Defenders on guard outside with a sharply upraised hand. He was not in the mood for their prattle.

hi stɔɹmd ɪnsaɪd, ən wɑz ənɔɪd tə faɪn ðət ðə ɡɑɹdz hæɾ əlaʊd sʌmwʌn ɪnsaɪd. ən ʌnfəmɪljɝ fɪɡjɝ stʊd wɪð ɪz bæk tə ɹænd, lʊkɪŋ aʊt ði oʊpən bælkəni dɔɹz. "wʌt - " ɹænd bɪɡæn.

He stormed inside, and was annoyed to find that the guards had allowed someone inside. An unfamiliar figure stood with his back to Rand, looking out the open balcony doors. "What - " Rand began.

ðə mæn tɝnd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ. nɑɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ əɾ ɔl.

The man turned. It was not a stranger. Not a stranger at all.

ɪt wɑz tæm. hɪz fɑðɝ.

It was Tam. His father.

ɹænd stʌmbəl bæk. wɑz ðɪs ən æpɝɪʃən? səm twɪstəd tʃɹɪk ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn? bʌt noʊ, ɪt wɑz tæm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðə mænz kaɪnli aɪz. ðoʊ hi wɑz ə hɛd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɹænd, tæm hæɾ ɔlweɪz simd mɔɹ sɑləd ðən ðə wɝld ɝaʊn hɪm. hɪz bɹɔd tʃɛst ən stɛɾi lɛɡz kəd nɑt bi muvd, nɑt kəz i wɑz stʃɹɔŋ - ɹænd hæd mɛt mɛni mɛn ʌv ɡɹeɪɾɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ dʊɹɪŋ ɪz tʃɹævəlz.

Rand stumbled back. Was this an apparition? Some twisted trick of the Dark One? But no, it was Tam. There was no mistaking the man's kindly eyes. Though he was a head shorter than Rand, Tam had always seemed more solid than the world around him. His broad chest and steady legs could not be moved, not because he was strong - Rand had met many men of greater strength during his travels.

stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz fliɾɪŋ. tæm wɑz ɹil. sɝɾən ən steɪbəl. dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm bɹɔt kʌmfɝt.

Strength was fleeting. Tam was real. Certain and stable. Just looking at him brought comfort.

bʌt kʌmfɝt klæʃt wɪð u ɹænd hæd bɪkʌm. hɪz wɝlz mɛt - ðə pɝsən i hæd bɪn, ðə pɝsən i hæd bɪkʌm - laɪk ə dʒɛɾ ʌv wɔɾɝ ɑn ə waɪt-hɑt stoʊn. wʌn ʃæɾɝɪŋ, ði ʌðɝ tɝnɪŋ tə stim.

But comfort clashed with who Rand had become. His worlds met - the person he had been, the person he had become - like a jet of water on a white-hot stone. One shattering, the other turning to steam.

tæm stʊd, hɛzɪɾənt, ɪn ðə bælkəni dɔɹweɪ, lɪt baɪ tu flɪkɝɪŋ læmps ɑn stænz ɪn ðə ɹum.

Tam stood, hesitant, in the balcony doorway, lit by two flickering lamps on stands in the room.

ɹænd ʌndɝstʊd tæmz hɛzəteɪʃən. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt blʌd fɑðɝ ən sʌn. ɹændz blʌd fɑðɝ hæd bɪn dʒɑnduən, klæn tʃif ə ðə tɑɹdæɾ il. tæm wɑz dʒʌs ðə mæn u hæd faʊn ɹænd ɑn ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt.

Rand understood Tam's hesitation. They were not blood father and son. Rand's blood father had been Janduin, clan chief of the Taardad Aiel. Tam was just the man who had found Rand on the slopes of Dragonmount.

dʒʌs ðə mæn u hæd ɹeɪz hɪm. dʒʌs ðə mæn u hæd tɔɾ ɪm ɛvɹiθɪŋ i nu. dʒʌs ðə mæn ɹænd lʌvd ən ɹɪvɪɹd, ən ɔlweɪz wʊd, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðɛɹ blʌd kənɛkʃən.

Just the man who had raised him. Just the man who had taught him everything he knew. Just the man Rand loved and revered, and always would, no matter what their blood connection.

"ɹænd." tæmz vɔɪs wɑz ɑkwɝd.

"Rand." Tam's voice was awkward.

"pliz," ɹænd sɛd θɹu hɪz ʃɑk. "pliz sɪt."

"Please," Rand said through his shock. "Please sit."

tæm nɑɾəd. hi kloʊz ðə bælkəni dɔɹz, ðən wɔk fɔɹwɝɾ ən tʊk wʌn ə ðə tʃɛɹz. ɹænd sæt, tu. ðeɪ stɛɹɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum ət wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðə stoʊn wɔlz wɝ bɛɹ; ɹænd pɹəfɝɾ əm ənɔɹnəmɛntɪd wɪð tæpəstʃɹiz əɹ peɪntɪŋz. ðə ɹʌɡ wɑz jɛloʊ ən ɹɛd, ən soʊ lɑɹdʒ ɪt ɹitʃt tə ɔl fɔɹ wɔlz.

Tam nodded. He closed the balcony doors, then walked forward and took one of the chairs. Rand sat, too. They stared across the room at one another. The stone walls were bare; Rand preferred them unornamented with tapestries or paintings. The rug was yellow and red, and so large it reached to all four walls.

ðə ɹum fɛl tu pɝfɛkt. ə veɪs ə fɹɛʃli kʌt dæɹə lɪliz ən kɑlimə blɑsəmz sæt ðɛɹ, ɹaɪt wɛɹ ɪt ʃʊd. tʃɛɹz ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, ɝeɪnʒd tu kɝɛkli. ðə ɹum dɪdn lʊk lɪvd ɪn. laɪk soʊ mɛni pleɪsəz i steɪd, ɪt wɑzn hoʊm. hi hædn tʃɹuli hæɾ ə hoʊm sɪns hid lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

The room felt too perfect. A vase of freshly cut dara lilies and calima blossoms sat there, right where it should. Chairs in the center, arranged too correctly. The room didn't look lived in. Like so many places he stayed, it wasn't home. He hadn't truly had a home since he'd left the Two Rivers.

tæm sæɾ ɪn wʌn tʃɛɹ, ɹænd ɪn ənʌðɝ. ɹænd ɹilaɪzd i stɪl hæd ði æksɛs ki ɪn ɪz hænd, soʊ hi sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə sʌn-pæɾɝnd ɹʌɡ bɪfɔɹ hɪm. tæm ɡlænst ət ɹændz stʌmp, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. hi klɛntʃt ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ, pɹɑbli wɪʃɪŋ i hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə wɝk ɑn. tæm wɑz ɔlweɪz mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ənkʌmftəɹbəl θɪŋz wən i hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪz hænz, wɛðɝ ɪt bi tʃɛkɪŋ ðə stʃɹæps ɑn ə hɑɹnəs əɹ ʃɪɹɪŋ ə ʃip.

Tam sat in one chair, Rand in another. Rand realized he still had the access key in his hand, so he set it on the sun-patterned rug before him. Tam glanced at Rand's stump, but said nothing. He clenched his hands together, probably wishing he had something to work on. Tam was always more comfortable talking about uncomfortable things when he had something to do with his hands, whether it be checking the straps on a harness or shearing a sheep.

laɪt, ɹænd θɔt, filɪŋ ə sʌɾən ɝdʒ tə ɪnfoʊl tæm ɪn ə hʌɡ. fəmɪljɛɹəɾi ən mɛmɹiz flʌɾəd bæk ɪndə hɪz maɪnd. tæm dɪlɪvɝɪŋ bɹændi tə ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn fəɹ bɛl taɪn. ðə plɛʒɝ tæm tʊk ɪn ɪz paɪp. hɪz peɪʃəns ən ɪz kaɪndnəs. hɪz ʌnɪkspɛktɪd hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd. aɪ noʊ hɪm soʊ wɛl. ən jɛɾ aɪv ɹɛɹli θɔɾ ə hɪm ɹisənli.

Light, Rand thought, feeling a sudden urge to enfold Tam in a hug. Familiarity and memories flooded back into his mind. Tam delivering brandy to the Winespring Inn for Bel Tine. The pleasure Tam took in his pipe. His patience and his kindness. His unexpected heron-mark sword. I know him so well. And yet I've rarely thought of him recently.

"haʊ . . ." ɹænd sɛd. "tæm, haʊ dɪd jə ɡɛt hɪɹ? haʊ dɪd jə faɪn mi?"

"How . . ." Rand said. "Tam, how did you get here? How did you find me?"

tæm tʃʌkəl kwaɪətli. "juv bɪn sɛndɪŋ nɑnstɑp mɛsənʒɝz tə ɔl ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz ðiz læs fju deɪz, tɛlɪŋ əm tə mɑɹʃəl ðɛɹ ɑɹmiz fəɹ wɔɹ. aɪ θɪŋk ə mæn wəɾ əv tə bi blaɪnd, dɛf ən dʒɹʌŋk nɑt tə noʊ wɛɹ tə faɪn ju."

Tam chuckled quietly. "You've been sending nonstop messengers to all the great cities these last few days, telling them to marshal their armies for war. I think a man would have to be blind, deaf and drunk not to know where to find you."

"bʌt maɪ mɛsənʒɝz hævənt ɡɔn tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz!"

"But my messengers haven't gone to the Two Rivers!"

"aɪ wɑzn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," tæm sɛd. "sʌm ʌv əs əv bɪn faɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd pɛɹɪn."

"I wasn't in the Two Rivers," Tam said. "Some of us have been fighting alongside Perrin."

ʌv kɔɹs, ɹænd θɔt. nɪneɪiv mʌst əv kɑntæktɪd pɛɹɪn - ðə kʌlɝz swɝld - ʃi wɑz soʊ wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɪm ən mæt. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn izi fəɹ tæm tə kʌm bæk wɪð hɝ.

Of course, Rand thought. Nynaeve must have contacted Perrin - the colors swirled - she was so worried about him and Mat. It would have been easy for Tam to come back with her.

wɑz ɹænd ɹɪli hævɪŋ ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən? hi hæd ɡɪvən ʌp ɑn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɑn ɛvɝ siɪŋ ɪz fɑðɝ əɡɛn. ɪt fɛl soʊ ɡʊd, dɪspaɪt ði ɔkwɝdnəs. tæmz feɪs hɛl mɔɹ laɪnz ðən ɪt hæd bɪfɔɹ, ən ðə fju dɪtɝmən stʃɹiks ə blæk ɪn ɪz hɛɹ hæd faɪnəli ɡɪvən ɪn ən ɡɔn sɪlvɝ, bʌɾ i wɑz ðə seɪm.

Was Rand really having this conversation? He had given up on returning to the Two Rivers, on ever seeing his father again. It felt so good, despite the awkwardness. Tam's face held more lines than it had before, and the few determined streaks of black in his hair had finally given in and gone silver, but he was the same.

soʊ mɛni pipəl hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɝaʊn ɹænd - mæt, pɛɹɪn, ɛɡwin, nɪneɪiv - ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ tə mit sʌmwʌn fɹəm ɪz oʊld laɪf u wɑz ðə seɪm. tæm, ðə mæn u hæd tɔt ɹænd tə sik ðə vɔɪd. tæm wɑz ə ɹɑk ðət sim tə hɪm stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðə stoʊn ɪtsɛlf.

So many people had changed around Rand - Mat, Perrin, Egwene, Nynaeve - it was a wonder to meet someone from his old life who was the same. Tam, the man who had taught Rand to seek the void. Tam was a rock that seemed to him stronger than the Stone itself.

ɹændz mud dɑɹkən slaɪtli. "weɪt. pɛɹɪn əz bɪn juzɪŋ tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk?"

Rand's mood darkened slightly. "Wait. Perrin has been using Two Rivers folk?"

tæm nɑɾəd. "hi niɾəd ʌs. ðət bɔɪz pʊɾ ɑn ə bælənsɪŋ æk tə ɪmpɹɛs ɛni mənædʒɝi pɝfɔɹmɝ. wʌt wɪð ðə sintʃæn ən ðə pɹɑfəts mɛn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə waɪtkloʊks ən ðə kwin - "

Tam nodded. "He needed us. That boy's put on a balancing act to impress any menagerie performer. What with the Seanchan and the Prophet's men, not to mention the Whitecloaks and the queen - "

"ðə kwin?" ɹænd sɛd.

"The queen?" Rand said.

"aɪ," tæm sɛd. "ðoʊ ʃi sɛz ʃiz nɑt kwin ɛnimɔɹ. ɪleɪnz mʌðɝ."

"Aye," Tam said. "Though she says she's not queen anymore. Elayne's mother."

"ʃi lɪvz, ðɛn?" ɹænd æskt.

"She lives, then?" Rand asked.

"ʃi dʌz, lɪɾəl θæŋks tə ðə waɪtkloʊks," tæm sɛd wɪð dɪsteɪst.

"She does, little thanks to the Whitecloaks," Tam said with distaste.

"hæz ʃi sin ɪleɪn?" ɹænd æskt. "ju mɛnʃənd waɪtkloʊks - haʊ dɪɾ i ɹʌn ɪndə waɪtkloʊks?" tæm bɪɡæn tə ænsɝ, bʌt ɹænd hɛld ʌp ɪz hænd. "noʊ. weɪt. aɪ kən ɡɛɾ ə ɹipɔɹt fɹəm pɛɹɪn wən aɪ wɪʃ ɪt. əl nɑɾ əv əɹ taɪm təɡɛðɝ spɛnt wɪð jə æktɪŋ ðə mɛsənʒɝ."

"Has she seen Elayne?" Rand asked. "You mentioned Whitecloaks - how did he run into Whitecloaks?" Tam began to answer, but Rand held up his hand. "No. Wait. I can get a report from Perrin when I wish it. I will not have our time together spent with you acting the messenger."

tæm smaɪl feɪnli.

Tam smiled faintly.

"wʌt?" ɹænd æskt.

"What?" Rand asked.

"ɑ, sʌn," hi sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, bɹɔd hɑɹdwɝkɪŋ hænz klæsp bɪfɔɹ hɪm, "ðeɪv ɹɪli dʌn ɪt. ðeɪv ɡɔn ən meɪɾ ə kɪŋ aʊɾ ə ju. wʌt hæpən tə ðə ɡæŋli bɔɪ, soʊ waɪd- aɪɾ ət bɛl taɪn? wɛɹz ði ənsɝɾən læɾ aɪ ɹeɪzd ɔl ðoʊz jɪɹz?"

"Ah, son," he said, shaking his head, broad hardworking hands clasped before him, "they've really done it. They've gone and made a king out of you. What happened to the gangly boy, so wide- eyed at Bel Tine? Where's the uncertain lad I raised all those years?"

"hiz dɛd," ɹænd sɛɾ ɪmiɾiətli.

"He's dead," Rand said immediately.

tæm nɑɾəd sloʊli. "aɪ kən si ðæt. jə . . . mʌs noʊ ðɛn. . . . əbaʊt. . . ."

Tam nodded slowly. "I can see that. You . . . must know then. . . . About. . . ."

"ðæt jəɹ nɑt maɪ fɑðɝ?" ɹænd ɡɛst.

"That you're not my father?" Rand guessed.

tæm nɑɾəd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn.

Tam nodded, looking down.

"aɪv noʊn sɪns ðə deɪ aɪ lɛft ɛmənz fild," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd. "ju spoʊk ʌv ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ fivɝ dʒɹimz. aɪ ɹəfjuz tə bɪliv ɪt fəɹ ə taɪm, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz ɪvɛntʃəwəli pɝsweɪɾəd."

"I've known since the day I left Emond's Field," Rand replied. "You spoke of it in your fever dreams. I refused to believe it for a time, but I was eventually persuaded."

"jɛs," tæm sɛd. "aɪ kən si haʊ. aɪ. . . ." hi ɡɹɪpt ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ taɪtli. "aɪ nɛvɝ mɛn tə laɪ tə ju, sʌn. ɔɹ, wɛl, aɪ ɡɛs aɪ ʃʊdn kɔl jə ðæt, ʃəɾ aɪ?"

"Yes," Tam said. "I can see how. I. . . ." He gripped his hands together tightly. "I never meant to lie to you, son. Or, well, I guess I shouldn't call you that, should I?"

jə kən kɔl mi sʌn, ɹænd θɔt. jə ɑɹ maɪ fɑðɝ. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt səm meɪ seɪ. bʌɾ i kʊdn fɔɹs ðə wɝdz aʊt.

You can call me son, Rand thought. You are my father. No matter what some may say. But he couldn't force the words out.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kʊdn əv ə fɑðɝ. ə fɑðɝ wəd bi ə wiknəs tə bi ɛksplɔɪɾəd, ivən mɔɹ ðən ə wʊmən laɪk mɪn. lʌvɝz wɝ ɪkspɛktəd. bʌt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd tə bi ə fɪɡjɝ ə mɪθ, ə kɹitʃɝ nɪɹli əz lɑɹdʒ əz ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf. hi hæd dɪfəkəlti ɡɛɾɪŋ pipəl tə oʊbeɪ əz ɪt wɑz.

The Dragon Reborn couldn't have a father. A father would be a weakness to be exploited, even more than a woman like Min. Lovers were expected. But the Dragon Reborn had to be a figure of myth, a creature nearly as large as the Pattern itself. He had difficulty getting people to obey as it was.

wʌt wəɾ ɪt də ɪf ɪt wɝ noʊn ðəɾ i kɛpt ɪz fɑðɝ nɪɹbaɪ? ɪf ɪt wɝ noʊn ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɹɪlaɪɾ əpɑn ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ʌv ə ʃɛpɝd?

What would it do if it were known that he kept his father nearby? If it were known that the Dragon Reborn relied upon the strength of a shepherd?

ðə kwaɪət vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɑɹt wɑz skɹimɪŋ.

The quiet voice in his heart was screaming.

"ju dɪd wɛl, tæm," ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf seɪɪŋ. "baɪ kipɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ fɹəm mi, jə laɪkli seɪv maɪ laɪf. ɪf pipəl hæd noʊn ðəɾ aɪ wɑz ə faʊnlɪŋ, ən dɪskʌvɝd nɪɹ dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt noʊ lɛs - wɛl, wɝd wəɾ əv spɹɛd. aɪ maɪt vɛɹi wɛl əv bɪn əsæsəneɪɾəd əz ə tʃaɪld."

"You did well, Tam," Rand found himself saying. "By keeping the truth from me, you likely saved my life. If people had known that I was a foundling, and discovered near Dragonmount no less - well, word would have spread. I might very well have been assassinated as a child."

"oʊ," tæm sɛd. "wɛl, ðɛn, aɪm ɡlæɾ aɪ dɪɾ ɪt."

"Oh," Tam said. "Well, then, I'm glad I did it."

ɹænd pɪkt ʌp ði æksɛs ki - ɪt tu bɹɔɾ ɪm kʌmfɝt - ðən stʊd. tæm heɪstəli dʒɔɪn hɪm, æktɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ laɪk dʒʌst ənʌðɝ ɹɪteɪnɝ əɹ sɝvənt.

Rand picked up the access key - it too brought him comfort - then stood. Tam hastily joined him, acting more and more like just another retainer or servant.

"ju hæv dʌn ə ɡɹeɪt sɝvəs, tæm ælθɹ," ɹænd sɛd. "baɪ pɹətɛktɪŋ ən ɹeɪzɪŋ mi, juv ʌʃɝɾ ɪn ə nu eɪdʒ. ðə wɝld oʊz jə ə dɛt. əl si ðət jə ɑɹ kɛɹd fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ laɪf."

"You have done a great service, Tam al'Thor," Rand said. "By protecting and raising me, you have ushered in a new Age. The world owes you a debt. I will see that you are cared for the rest of your life."

"aɪ əpɹiʃieɪt ðæt, maɪ lɔɹd," tæm sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪzənt nɛsəsɛɹi. aɪ hæv wʌɾ aɪ nid."

"I appreciate that, my Lord," Tam said. "But it isn't necessary. I have what I need."

wɑz i haɪɾɪŋ ə ɡɹɪn? pɝhæps ɪt hæd bɪn ə pɑmpəs spitʃ. ðə ɹum fɛl staɪflɪŋ, ən ɹænd tɝnd, kɹɔsɪŋ ðə faɪn ɹʌɡ ən θɹoʊɪŋ oʊpən ðə bælkəni dɔɹz əɡɛn. ðə sʌn hæɾ ɪndid sɛt, ən dɑɹknəs hæd fɔlən ɑn ðə sɪɾi. ə kɹɪsp oʊʃən bɹiz blu əkɹɔs ɪm əz i stɛpt aʊt tə ðə bælkəni ɹeɪlɪŋ, ɪndə ðə naɪt.

Was he hiding a grin? Perhaps it had been a pompous speech. The room felt stifling, and Rand turned, crossing the fine rug and throwing open the balcony doors again. The sun had indeed set, and darkness had fallen on the city. A crisp ocean breeze blew across him as he stepped out to the balcony railing, into the night.

tæm stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm.

Tam stepped up beside him.

"aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪ lɔs jəɹ sɔɹd," ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf seɪɪŋ. ɪt fɛl fulɪʃ.

"I'm afraid I lost your sword," Rand found himself saying. It felt foolish.

"ðæts ɔl ɹaɪt," tæm sɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðəɾ aɪ ɛvɝ dɪzɝv ðə θɪŋ ɛniweɪ."

"That's all right," Tam said. "I don't know that I ever deserved the thing anyway."

"wɝ jə ɹɪli ə bleɪdmæstɝ?"

"Were you really a blademaster?"

tæm nɑɾəd. "aɪ səpoʊz. aɪ kɪld ə mæn u wɑz wʌn, dɪɾ ɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wɪtnəsəz, bʌɾ aɪv nɛvɝ fɝɡɪvən maɪsɛlf fəɹ ɪt. ðoʊ ɪt niɾəd duɪŋ."

Tam nodded. "I suppose. I killed a man who was one, did it in front of witnesses, but I've never forgiven myself for it. Though it needed doing."

"ðə wʌnz ðət nid tə bi dʌn ɔfən sim ðə wʌnz ðət wi lis laɪk tə hæv tə du."

"The ones that need to be done often seem the ones that we least like to have to do."

"ðæts ðə tʃɹuθ ɪf aɪv ɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪt," tæm sɛd, saɪɪŋ sɔfli, linɪŋ ɑn ðə bælkəni ɹeɪlɪŋ. lɪt wɪndoʊz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃaɪn ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs bɪloʊ. "ɪts soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ. maɪ bɔɪ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɔl ə ðoʊz stɔɹiz aɪ hɝd wən tʃɹævlɪŋ ðə wɝld, aɪm pɑɹɾ ə ðɛm."

"That's the truth if I've ever heard it," Tam said, sighing softly, leaning on the balcony railing. Lit windows were beginning to shine in the darkness below. "It's so strange. My boy, the Dragon Reborn. All of those stories I heard when traveling the world, I'm part of them."

"θɪŋk haʊ ɪt filz fəɹ mi," ɹænd sɛd.

"Think how it feels for me," Rand said.

tæm tʃʌkəld. "jɛs. jɛs, aɪ səpoʊz jə ʌndɝstæn ɪɡzækli wʌɾ aɪ min, doʊn ju? fʌni, ɪzən ɪt?"

Tam chuckled. "Yes. Yes, I suppose you understand exactly what I mean, don't you? Funny, isn't it?"

"fʌni?" ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ. nɑt, ðæt. maɪ laɪf ɪzən maɪ oʊn. ɪm ə pʌpət fəɹ ðə pæɾɝn ən ðə pɹɑfəsiz, meɪd tə dæns fəɹ ðə wɝl bɪfɔɹ hævɪŋ maɪ stʃɹɪŋz kʌt."

"Funny?" Rand shook his head. "No. Not, that. My life isn't my own. I'm a puppet for the Pattern and the prophecies, made to dance for the world before having my strings cut."

tæm fɹaʊnd. "ðæts nɑt tʃɹu, sʌn. ɝ, maɪ lɔɹd."

Tam frowned. "That's not true, son. Er, my Lord."

"aɪ kæn si ɪɾ ɛni ʌðɝ weɪ."

"I can't see it any other way."

tæm kɹɔst ɪz ɑɹmz ɑn ðə smuð stoʊn ɹeɪlɪŋ. "aɪ ɡɛs aɪ kən ʌndɝstænd. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ səm ə ðoʊz ɪmoʊʃənz maɪsɛlf, dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪz wən aɪ wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ. jə noʊ ðəɾ aɪ fɔɾ əɡɛns tiɹ?

Tam crossed his arms on the smooth stone railing. "I guess I can understand. I remember some of those emotions myself, during the days when I was a soldier. You know that I fought against Tear?

jud θɪŋk aɪ wəɾ əv peɪnfəl mɛmɹiz, kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ. bʌt wʌn ɛnəmi ɔfən kʌmz tə sim laɪk ənʌðɝ. aɪ doʊn bɛɹ ɛni ɡɹʌdʒɪz."

You'd think I would have painful memories, coming here. But one enemy often comes to seem like another. I don't bear any grudges."

ɹænd ɹɛstəd ði æksɛs ki ɑn ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, bʌt hɛld ɪt taɪtli. hi dɪd nɑt lin daʊn; hi ɹɪmeɪn stʃɹeɪt-bækt.

Rand rested the access key on the railing, but held it tightly. He did not lean down; he remained straight-backed.

"ə soʊlʒɝ dʌzn əv ə lɑɾ ə tʃɔɪsəz fəɹ ɪz oʊn dɛstəni iðɝ," tæm sɛd, tæpɪŋ sɔfli ɑn ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ wɪð ən aɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ. "mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mɛn meɪk ɔl ðə dɪsɪʒənz. mɛn, wɛl, aɪ ɡɛs mɛn laɪk ju."

"A soldier doesn't have a lot of choices for his own destiny either," Tam said, tapping softly on the railing with an idle finger. "More important men make all the decisions. Men, well, I guess men like you."

"bʌt maɪ tʃɔɪsəz ɑɹ meɪd fəɹ mi baɪ ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ hæv lɛs fɹiɾəm ðən ðə soʊlʒɝz. jə kəɾ əv ɹʌn, dɪzɝɾɪd. əɹ ət list ɡɑɾən aʊt baɪ liɡəl minz."

"But my choices are made for me by the Pattern itself," Rand said. "I have less freedom than the soldiers. You could have run, deserted. Or at least gotten out by legal means."

"æn jə kæn ɹʌn?" tæm æskt.

"And you can't run?" Tam asked.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðə pæɾɝn wəd lɛt mi," ɹænd sɛd. "wʌɾ aɪ də ɪz tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ɪt wəd dʒʌs fɔɹs mi bæk ɪn laɪn. ɪts dʌn soʊ ə dʌzən taɪmz ɔlɹɛɾi."

"I don't think the Pattern would let me," Rand said. "What I do is too important. It would just force me back in line. It has done so a dozen times already."

"ænd wəd jə ɹɪli wɑnə ɹʌn?" tæm æskt.

"And would you really want to run?" Tam asked.

ɹænd dɪdn ɹɪplaɪ.

Rand didn't reply.

"aɪ cʊɾə lɛf ðoʊz wɔɹz. bʌt, ət ðə seɪm taɪm, aɪ kʊdn hæv. nɑt wɪθaʊt bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ u aɪ wɑz. aɪ θɪŋk ɪts ðə seɪm fəɹ ju. dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ ɪf jə kən ɹʌn, wən jə noʊ ðət jəɹ nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə?"

"I could have left those wars. But, at the same time, I couldn't have. Not without betraying who I was. I think it's the same for you. Does it matter if you can run, when you know that you're not going to?"

"aɪm gɑnə daɪ ət ði ɛn ə ðɪs," ɹænd sɛd. "æn aɪ hæv noʊ tʃɔɪs."

"I'm going to die at the end of this," Rand said. "And I have no choice."

tæm stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ɪn ən ɪnstənt, ɹænd fɛl ðəɾ i wɑz twɛlv jɪɹz oʊld əɡɛn. "aɪ woʊn əv tɔk laɪk ðæt," tæm sɛd. "ivən ɪf jəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, aɪ woʊn lɪsən tə ɪt. jə ɔlweɪz əv ə tʃɔɪs. meɪbi jə kæn pɪk wɛɹ jə ɑɹ fɔɹs tə ɡoʊ, bʌt jə stɪl əv ə tʃɔɪs."

Tam stood up straight, frowning. In an instant, Rand felt that he was twelve years old again. "I won't have talk like that," Tam said. "Even if you're the Dragon Reborn, I won't listen to it. You always have a choice. Maybe you can't pick where you are forced to go, but you still have a choice."

"bʌt haʊ?"

"But how?"

tæm leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɹændz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðə tʃɔɪs ɪzən ɔlweɪz əbaʊt wʌt jə du, sʌn, bʌt waɪ jə də ɪt. wən aɪ wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ, ðəɹ wɝ səm mɛn u fɔt sɪmpli fəɹ ðə mʌni. ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz u fɔt fəɹ lɔɪəlti - lɔɪəlti tə ðɛɹ kɑmɹædz, əɹ tə ðə kɹaʊn, əɹ tə wʌtɛvɝ. ðə soʊlʒɝ u daɪz fəɹ mʌni ən ðə soʊlʒɝ u daɪz fəɹ lɔɪəlti ɑɹ boʊθ dɛd, bʌt ðɛɹz ə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ðɛm. wʌn dɛθ mɛn sʌmθɪŋ. ði ʌðɝ dɪdnt.

Tam laid a hand on Rand's shoulder. "The choice isn't always about what you do, son, but why you do it. When I was a soldier, there were some men who fought simply for the money. There were others who fought for loyalty - loyalty to their comrades, or to the crown, or to whatever. The soldier who dies for money and the soldier who dies for loyalty are both dead, but there's a difference between them. One death meant something. The other didn't.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ɪts tʃɹu ðət jəl nid tə daɪ fəɹ ðɪs ɔl tə pleɪ aʊt. bʌt wi boʊθ noʊ jə ɑɹən gɑnə ɹʌn fɹəm ɪt. tʃeɪnʒd ðoʊ jə ɑɹ, aɪ kən si ðət səm θɪŋz ɑɹ ðə seɪm. soʊ aɪ woʊn stæn ɛni waɪnɪŋ ɑn ðə sʌbʒɪkt."

"I don't know if it's true that you'll need to die for this all to play out. But we both know you aren't going to run from it. Changed though you are, I can see that some things are the same. So I won't stand any whining on the subject."

"aɪ wɑznt waɪnɪŋ - " ɹænd bɪɡæn.

"I wasn't whining - " Rand began.

"aɪ noʊ," tæm sɛd. "kɪŋz doʊnt waɪn, ðeɪ dɪlɪbɝɪt." hi sim tə bi kwoʊɾɪŋ sʌmwʌn, ðoʊ ɹænd hæd noʊ aɪdiə hu. ɑdli, tæm ɡeɪv ə bɹif tʃʌkəl. "ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ," tæm kəntɪnjud.

"I know," Tam said. "Kings don't whine, they deliberate." He seemed to be quoting someone, though Rand had no idea who. Oddly, Tam gave a brief chuckle. "It doesn't matter," Tam continued.

"ɹænd, aɪ θɪŋk jə kən sɝvaɪv ðɪs. aɪ kæn ɪmædʒən ðət ðə pæɾɝn woʊnt ɡɪv jə səm pis, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə sɝvəs jəɹ duɪŋ fəɹ əs ɔl. bʌt jəɹ ə soʊlʒɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə wɔɹ, ən ðə fɝs θɪŋ ə soʊlʒɝ lɝnz ɪz ðət jə maɪt daɪ. jə meɪ nɑt bi eɪbəl tə tʃuz ðə duɾiz jəɹ ɡɪvən. bʌt jə kən tʃuz waɪ jə fʊlfɪl ðɛm. waɪ dʒju ɡoʊ tə bæɾəl, ɹænd?"

"Rand, I think you can survive this. I can't imagine that the Pattern won't give you some peace, considering the service you're doing for us all. But you're a soldier going to war, and the first thing a soldier learns is that you might die. You may not be able to choose the duties you're given. But you can choose why you fulfill them. Why do you go to battle, Rand?"

"bɪkɔz aɪ mʌst."

"Because I must."

"ðæts nɑt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf," tæm sɛd. "tə ðə kɹoʊz wɪð ðət wʊmən! aɪ wɪʃ ʃid kʌm tə mi sunɝ. ɪf aɪd noʊn - "

"That's not good enough," Tam said. "To the crows with that woman! I wish she'd come to me sooner. If I'd known - "

"wʌt wʊmən?"

"What woman?"

"kædzueɪn sədaɪ," tæm sɛd. "ʃi bɹɔt mi hɪɹ, sɛd ðəɾ aɪ niɾəd tə tɔk tə ju. aɪd steɪɾ əweɪ, pɹiviəsli, kəz aɪ θɔt ðə læs θɪŋ jə niɾəd wɑz jəɹ fɑðɝ stɑmpɪŋ əkɹɔs jəɹ fild!"

"Cadsuane Sedai," Tam said. "She brought me here, said that I needed to talk to you. I'd stayed away, previously, because I thought the last thing you needed was your father stomping across your field!"

tæm kəntɪnjud, bʌt ɹænd stɑp lɪsnɪŋ.

Tam continued, but Rand stopped listening.

kædzueɪn. tæm hæd kʌm kəz ə kædzueɪn. ɪt wɑzn kəz tæm hæd noʊɾəst nɪneɪiv ən teɪkən ði ɑpɝtunəɾi. nɑt kəz hid dʒʌst wɑntəd tə tʃɛk ɑn ɪz sʌn. bʌt kəz hid bɪn mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd ɪndə kʌmɪŋ.

Cadsuane. Tam had come because of Cadsuane. It wasn't because Tam had noticed Nynaeve and taken the opportunity. Not because he'd just wanted to check on his son. But because he'd been manipulated into coming.

wəd ðə wʊmən nɛvɝ liv ɹænd əloʊn!

Would the woman never leave Rand alone!

hɪz ɪmoʊʃənz siɪŋ tæm wɝ soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət ðeɪ hæd wɔɹn əweɪ ði aɪs. tu mʌtʃ əfɛkʃən wɑz laɪk tu mʌtʃ heɪtʃɹəd. iðɝ wʌn meɪɾ ɪm fil, wɪtʃ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ i kəd nɑt ɹɪsk.

His emotions seeing Tam were so strong that they had worn away the ice. Too much affection was like too much hatred. Either one made him feel, which was something he could not risk.

bʌɾ i hæd. ən sʌɾənli, filɪŋ nɪɹli oʊvɝkeɪm hɪm. hi ʃʌɾɝəd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm tæm.

But he had. And suddenly, feeling nearly overcame him. He shuddered, turning away from Tam.

hæd ðɛɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɔl bɪn ənʌðɝ wʌn ə kædzueɪnz ɡeɪmz? wʌt wɑz tæmz pɑɹɾ ɪn ɪt?

Had their conversation all been another one of Cadsuane's games? What was Tam's part in it?

"ɹænd?" tæm æskt. "aɪm sɑɹi. aɪ ʃʊdn əv bɹɔɾ ʌp ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi sɛd jə maɪt bi æŋɡɹi ɪf aɪ mɛnʃən hɝ."

"Rand?" Tam asked. "I'm sorry. I shouldn't have brought up the Aes Sedai. She said you might be angry if I mentioned her."

"wʌɾ ɛls dɪd ʃi seɪ?" ɹænd dɪmændəd, spɪnɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd tæm. ðə staʊt mæn tʊk ə hɛzɪɾənt stɛp bækwɝd. naɪɾ ɛɹ blu ɝaʊn ðɛm, laɪts fɹəm ðə sɪɾi dɑts bɪloʊ.

"What else did she say?" Rand demanded, spinning back toward Tam. The stout man took a hesitant step backward. Night air blew around them, lights from the city dots below.

"wɛl," tæm sɛd, "ʃi toʊl mi ðəɾ aɪ ʃəd tɔk əbaʊt jəɹ juθ, ɹimaɪn jə ʌv bɛɾɝ taɪmz.

"Well," Tam said, "she told me that I should talk about your youth, remind you of better times.

ʃi θɔt - "

She thought - "

"ʃi mənɪpjəleɪts mi!" ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, miɾɪŋ tæmz aɪz. "ænd ʃi mənɪpjəleɪts ju.

"She manipulates me!" Rand said softly, meeting Tam's eyes. "And she manipulates you.

ɛvɹiwʌn taɪz ðɛɹ stʃɹɪŋz tə mi!"

Everyone ties their strings to me!"

ðə ɹeɪdʒ bɔɪld ɪnsaɪd. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ʃʌv ɪt bæk, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz soʊ dɪfəkəlt. wɛɹ wɑz ði aɪs, ðə kwaɪət? dɛspɝətli, ɹænd sɔt ðə vɔɪd. hi tʃɹaɪd pɔɹɪŋ ɔl ə hɪz ɪmoʊʃənz ɪndə ðə fleɪm ʌv ə kændəl, əz tæm hæd tɔt soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ.

The rage boiled inside. He tried to shove it back, but it was so difficult. Where was the ice, the quiet? Desperately, Rand sought the void. He tried pouring all of his emotions into the flame of a candle, as Tam had taught so long ago.

seɪɾɪn wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ. wɪθaʊt θɔt, ɹænd sizd ɪt, ən ɪn duɪŋ soʊ wɑz oʊvɝwɛlmd wɪð ðoʊz ɪmoʊʃənz i θɔt hiɾ əbændənd. ðə vɔɪd ʃæɾɝd, bʌt sʌmhaʊ seɪɾɪn ɹɪmeɪnd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ əɡɛns hɪm. hi skɹimd əz ðə nɔziə hɪt hɪm, ən i θɹu hɪz æŋɡɝ əɡɛnst ɪɾ ɪn dɪfaɪəns.

Saidin was waiting there. Without thought, Rand seized it, and in doing so was overwhelmed with those emotions he thought he'd abandoned. The void shattered, but somehow saidin remained, struggling against him. He screamed as the nausea hit him, and he threw his anger against it in defiance.

"ɹænd," tæm sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "ju ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən - "

"Rand," Tam said, frowning. "You should know better than - "

"bi saɪlənt! " ɹænd bɛloʊd, θɹoʊɪŋ tæm tə ðə flɔɹ wɪð ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ. ɹænd ɹɛsəld wɪð ɪz ɹeɪdʒ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən seɪɾɪn ɑn ði ʌðɝ. ðeɪ θɹɛɾənd tə kɹʌʃ ɪm bɪtwin ðɛm.

"BE SILENT! " Rand bellowed, throwing Tam to the floor with a flow of Air. Rand wrestled with his rage on one side and saidin on the other. They threatened to crush him between them.

ðɪs wɑz waɪ hi niɾəd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ. kʊdn ðeɪ si? haʊ kəɾ ə mæn læf wən kənfɹʌntəd baɪ fɔɹsɪz laɪk ðiz?

This was why he needed to be strong. Couldn't they see? How could a man laugh when confronted by forces like these?

"aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!" ɹænd ɹɔɹɾ ət seɪɾɪn, ət tæm, ət kædzueɪn, ət ðə kɹieɪɾɝ hɪmsɛlf. "aɪ wɪl nɑt bi jəɹ pɔn!" hi pɔɪntəɾ ət tæm wɪð ði æksɛs ki. hɪz fɑðɝ leɪ ɑn ðə stoʊn flɔɹ ə ðə bælkəni. "ju kʌm fɹəm kædzueɪn, pɹitɛndɪŋ tə ʃoʊ mi əfɛkʃən. bʌt jə ənwaɪn ənʌðɝ ə hɝ stʃɹɪŋz tə taɪ əbaʊt maɪ θɹoʊt! kən aɪ nɑt bi fɹi ʌv jə ɔl?"

"I am the Dragon Reborn!" Rand roared at saidin, at Tam, at Cadsuane, at the Creator himself. "I will not be your pawn!" He pointed at Tam with the access key. His father lay on the stone floor of the balcony. "You come from Cadsuane, pretending to show me affection. But you unwind another of her strings to tie about my throat! Can I not be free of you all?"

hi hæd lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl. bʌɾ i dɪdn kɛɹ. ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ɪm tə fil. hi wəd fil, ðɛn! ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ɪm tə læf? hi wəd læf əz ðeɪ bɝnd!

He had lost control. But he didn't care. They wanted him to feel. He would feel, then! They wanted him to laugh? He would laugh as they burned!

skɹimɪŋ əɾ əm ɔl, hi woʊv θɹɛdz ʌv ɛɹ ən faɪɝ. luz θɝɪn haʊld ɪn ɪz hɛd, seɪɾɪn tʃɹaɪd tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ boʊθ ə ðɛm, ən ðə kwaɪət vɔɪs ɪnsaɪd ɹændz hɑɹt vænɪʃt.

Screaming at them all, he wove threads of Air and Fire. Lews Therin howled in his head, saidin tried to destroy both of them, and the quiet voice inside Rand's heart vanished.

ə pɹɪk ə laɪt ɡɹu ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹænd, spɹaʊɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ ə ði æksɛs ki. ðə wivz fəɹ bɑlfaɪɝ spʌn bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ən ði æksɛs ki ɡɹu bɹaɪɾɝ əz i dʒɹu ɪn mɔɹ paʊɝ.

A prick of light grew in front of Rand, sprouting from the center of the access key. The weaves for balefire spun before him, and the access key grew brighter as he drew in more power.

baɪ ðət laɪt, ɹænd sɔ hɪz fɑðɝz feɪs, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm.

By that light, Rand saw his father's face, looking up at him.

tɛɹəfaɪd.

Terrified.

wʌɾ æm aɪ duɪŋ?

What am I doing?

ɹænd bɪɡæn tə ʃeɪk, ðə bɑlfaɪɝ ənɹævəlɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i hæd taɪm tə lus ɪt. hi stʌmbəl bækwɝɾ ɪn hɔɹɝ.

Rand began to shake, the balefire unraveling before he had time to loose it. He stumbled backward in horror.

wʌɾ æm aɪ duɪŋ? ɹænd θɔɾ əɡɛn.

What am I DOING? Rand thought again.

noʊ mɔɹ ðən aɪv dʌn bɪfɔɹ, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd.

No more than I've done before, Lews Therin whispered.

tæm kəntɪnjud tə stɛɹ ət hɪm, feɪs ʃæɾoʊd baɪ ðə naɪt.

Tam continued to stare at him, face shadowed by the night.

oʊ, laɪt, ɹænd θɔt wɪð tɛɹɝ, ʃɑk ən ɹeɪdʒ. aɪm duɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛn. aɪm ə mɑnstɝ.

Oh, Light, Rand thought with terror, shock and rage. I am doing it again. I am a monster.

stɪl hoʊldɪŋ tɛnjuəsli tə seɪɾɪn, ɹænd woʊv ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ɛbu dɑɹ, ðən dʌk θɹu, fliɪŋ fɹəm ðə hɔɹɝ ɪn tæmz aɪz.

Still holding tenuously to saidin, Rand wove a gateway to Ebou Dar, then ducked through, fleeing from the horror in Tam's eyes.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾieɪt

CHAPTER 48

ɹiɾɪŋ ðə kɑməntɛɹi mɪn sæɾ ɪn kædzueɪnz smɔl ɹum, weɪɾɪŋ - wɪð ði ʌðɝz - tə hɪɹ ðə ɹɪzʌlt ə ɹændz miɾɪŋ wɪð ɪz fɑðɝ. ə loʊ faɪɝ bɝn ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən læmps əɾ itʃ kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum lɛn laɪt tə ðə wɪmən, hu wɝkt ət vɛɹiəs bʌsiɪŋ æktɪvəɾiz - ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, dɑɹnɪŋ, ən nɪɾɪŋ - tə kip ðɛɹ maɪnz ɔf ə ðə weɪt.

Reading the Commentary Min sat in Cadsuane's small room, waiting - with the others - to hear the result of Rand's meeting with his father. A low fire burned in the fireplace and lamps at each corner of the room lent light to the women, who worked at various busying activities - embroidery, darning, and knitting - to keep their minds off of the wait.

mɪn wɑz pæst ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ dɪsɪʒən tə meɪk ən əlaɪəns wɪð kædzueɪn. ɹəɡɹɛt hæd kʌm ɝli, dʊɹɪŋ ðə fɝs fju deɪz wən kædzueɪn hæd kɛp mɪn kloʊs, æskɪŋ æftɝ ɛvɹi vjuɪŋ ʃi hæd hæɾ əbaʊt ɹænd. ðə wʊmən wɑz mətɪkjələs əz ə bɹaʊn, ɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn itʃ vɪʒən ən ænsɝ. ɪt wɑz laɪk biɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, əɡɛn!

Min was past regretting her decision to make an alliance with Cadsuane. Regret had come early, during the first few days when Cadsuane had kept Min close, asking after every viewing she had had about Rand. The woman was meticulous as a Brown, writing down each vision and answer. It was like being in the White Tower, again!

mɪn wɑzn sɝɾən waɪ nɪneɪivz səbmɪʃən tə kædzueɪn hæd ɡɪvən ðə wʊmən laɪsəns tə ɪntɛɹəɡeɪt mɪn, bʌt ðət wɑz haʊ kædzueɪn sim tə ɪntɝpɹəɾ ɪt. mɪks ðət wɪð mɪnz dɪskʌmfɝɾ ɝaʊn ɹænd leɪtli ən əɹ oʊn dɪzaɪɝ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt dʒʌst wʌt kædzueɪn ən ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ plænɪŋ, ən ʃi sim tə spɛn pɹæktəkli ɔl ə hɝ taɪm ɪn ðə wʊmənz pɹɛzəns.

Min wasn't certain why Nynaeve's submission to Cadsuane had given the woman license to interrogate Min, but that was how Cadsuane seemed to interpret it. Mix that with Min's discomfort around Rand lately and her own desire to figure out just what Cadsuane and the Wise Ones were planning, and she seemed to spend practically all of her time in the woman's presence.

jɛs, ɹəɡɹɛt hæd kʌm ən ɡɔn. mɪn hæd muvd ɑn tə ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən, tɪŋd wɪð ə hɪn ə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən.

Yes, regret had come and gone. Min had moved on to resignation, tinged with a hint of frustration.

kædzueɪn nu kwaɪɾ ə bɪɾ əbaʊt ðə mətɪɹiəl mɪn wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ɪn əɹ bʊks, bʌt ðə wʊmən doʊld aʊɾ əɹ nɑlədʒ laɪk klaʊdbɛɹi dʒæm, ə lɪɾəl ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ ɡʊd bɪheɪvjɝ, ɔlweɪz hɪntɪŋ ðət ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə kʌm. ðət kɛp mɪn fɹəm fliɪŋ.

Cadsuane knew quite a bit about the material Min was studying in her books, but the woman doled out her knowledge like cloudberry jam, a little reward for good behavior, always hinting that there was more to come. That kept Min from fleeing.

ʃi hæd tə faɪn ði ænsɝz. ɹænd niɾəd ðɛm.

She had to find the answers. Rand needed them.

wɪð ðət θɔɾ ɪn maɪnd, mɪn lin bæk ɑn əɹ kʊʃən bɛntʃ ən ɹioʊpən əɹ kɝən bʊk, ə wɝk baɪ seɪdʒiɪs ðət wɑz sɪmpli taɪɾəld kɑməntɛɹi ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən. wʌn laɪn ɪn ɪt tizd ət hɝ, ə sɛntəns moʊsli ɪɡnɔɹd baɪ ðoʊz u hæd ɹɪɾən kɑməntɛɹi. hi ʃæl hoʊld ə bleɪɾ ə laɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, ən ðə θɹi ʃæl bi wʌn.

With that thought in mind, Min leaned back on her cushioned bench and reopened her current book, a work by Sajius that was simply titled Commentary on the Dragon. One line in it teased at her, a sentence mostly ignored by those who had written commentary. He shall hold a blade of light in his hands, and the three shall be one.

ðə kɑmənteɪɾɝz fɛlt ɪt wɑz tu veɪɡ kəmpɛɹd wɪð ʌðɝ pæsədʒəz, laɪk ɹænd teɪkɪŋ ðə stoʊn əɹ ɹændz blʌd biɪŋ spɪld ɑn ðə ɹɑks ə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

The commentators felt it was too vague compared with other passages, like Rand taking the Stone or Rand's blood being spilled on the rocks of Shayol Ghul.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðət læst wʌn. ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ wɑz ðət mɛni ʌv ðə pɹɑfəsiz -  wɪð ə lɪɾəl kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən ən θɔt - dʒɛnɝəli meɪd sɛns. ivən ðə laɪnz əbaʊt ɹænd biɪŋ mɑɹk baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡənz ən ðə hɛɹənz meɪd sɛns, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt naʊ.

She tried not to think about that last one. The important thing was that many of the prophecies -  with a little consideration and thought - generally made sense. Even the lines about Rand being marked by the Dragons and the Herons made sense, looking at it now.

bʌt wʌɾ ə ðɪs laɪn? ə bleɪɾ ə laɪɾ ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli mɛn kælændɝ. bʌt wʌɾ ə ðə "θɹi ʃæl bi wʌn"? səm fju skɑlɝz kleɪm ðət "ðə θɹi" wɝ θɹi ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz - tɛɹ, ɪljən ən keɪɛmlɪn. ɔɹəɡən, ɪf wʌn hæpən tə bi ə skɑlɝ fɹəm kɛɹhin, ðən ðeɪ wɝ sɛd tə bi tɛɹ, ɪljən ən kɛɹhin. ðə pɹɑbləm wɑz ðət ɹænd hæd junaɪɾəd fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən θɹi sɪɾiz. hid kɑŋkɝd bændɑɹ ɛbən əz wɛl, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə fæk ðəɾ i wəd nid tə bɹɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz tə hɪz bænɝ.

But what of this line? A blade of light almost certainly meant Callandor. But what of the "three shall be one"? Some few scholars claimed that "the three" were three great cities - Tear, Illian and Caemlyn. Or, if one happened to be a scholar from Cairhien, then they were said to be Tear, Illian and Cairhien. The problem was that Rand had united far more than three cities. He'd conquered Bandar Eban as well, not to mention the fact that he would need to bring the Borderlanders to his banner.

bʌɾ i wɑz ɹulɝ - əɹ nɪɹ tə ɪt - ɪn θɹi kɪŋdəmz. hid ɡɪvən ʌp ændɝ, bʌt kɛɹhin, ɪljən ən tiɹ wɝ dɝɛkli bɪniθ ɪz kəntʃɹoʊl, ivən ɪf i pɝsənəli wɔɹ oʊnli wʌn kɹaʊn. meɪbi ðɪs pæsədʒ dɪd min wʌt ðə skɑlɝz sɛd, ən mɪn wɑz tʃeɪsɪŋ nʌθɪŋ.

But he was ruler - or near to it - in three kingdoms. He'd given up Andor, but Cairhien, Illian and Tear were directly beneath his control, even if he personally wore only one crown. Maybe this passage did mean what the scholars said, and Min was chasing nothing.

wɝ əɹ stʌɾiz əz jusləs əz ðə pɹətɛkʃən ʃid θɔt tə ɔfɝ ɹænd? mɪn, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf, sɛlf-pɪɾi wɪl ɡɛt jə noʊwɛɹ. ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz stʌɾi, θɪŋk ən hoʊp.

Were her studies as useless as the protection she'd thought to offer Rand? Min, she told herself, self-pity will get you nowhere. All she could do was study, think and hope.

"ðɪs ɪz ɹɔŋ," ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf seɪɪŋ aʊt laʊd.

"This is wrong," she found herself saying out loud.

ʃi hɝd bɛldaɪnz sɔfli dɝɪsɪv snɔɹt fɹəm əkɹɔs ðə ɹum. mɪn lʊkt ʌp, fɹaʊnɪŋ.

She heard Beldeine's softly derisive snort from across the room. Min looked up, frowning.

ðə wɪmən u hæd swɔɹn tə ɹænd - ɛɹiən, nɛsun, sɝin ən bɛldaɪn - hæd faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz lɛs wɛlkəm ɪn ɪz pɹɛzəns əz i hæd ɡɹoʊn lɛs tʃɹʌstɪŋ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. ði oʊnli wʌn i ɹɛɡjəlɝli əlaʊd tə si hɪm wɑz nɪneɪiv. ɪt wɑzn ɑd, ðɛn, ðət ði ʌðɝz hæd faʊn ðɛɹ weɪ tə kædzueɪnz "kæmp."

The women who had sworn to Rand - Erian, Nesune, Sarene and Beldeine - had found themselves less welcome in his presence as he had grown less trusting of Aes Sedai. The only one he regularly allowed to see him was Nynaeve. It wasn't odd, then, that the others had found their way to Cadsuane's "camp."

ən wʌɾ ə mɪnz oʊn ɹileɪʃənʃɪp wɪð ɹænd? ʃi wɑz stɪl wɛlkəm ɪn ɪz pɹɛzəns; ðət hædn tʃeɪnʒd. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ, sʌmθɪŋ ɔf. hi pʊɾ ʌp wɔlz wən ʃi wɑz nɪɹ -  nɑt tə kip əɹ aʊt, bʌt tə kip ðə ɹil ɪm ɪn. əz ɪf i wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ʌv wʌt ðə ɹil ɪm wəd du, əɹ kəd du, tə ðoʊz i lʌvd. . . .

And what of Min's own relationship with Rand? She was still welcome in his presence; that hadn't changed. But there was something wrong, something off. He put up walls when she was near -  not to keep her out, but to keep the real him in. As if he was afraid of what the real him would do, or could do, to those he loved. . . .

hiz ɪn peɪn əɡɛn, ʃi θɔt, filɪŋ ɪm θɹu ðə bɑnd. sətʃ æŋɡɝ. wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?

He's in pain again, she thought, feeling him through the bond. Such anger. What was going on?

ʃi fɛlt ə spaɪk ə fɪɹ, bʌt ʃʌvd ɪt daʊn. ʃi hæd tə tʃɹʌst ɪn kædzueɪnz plæn. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd wʌn.

She felt a spike of fear, but shoved it down. She had to trust in Cadsuane's plan. It was a good one.

kɔɹəl ən mɛɹaɪs - ɔlmoʊs kɑnstən ətɛndəns ə kædzueɪn ðiz deɪz - kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɪn mætʃɪŋ tʃɛɹz baɪ ðə hɑɹθ. kædzueɪn hæd sədʒɛstəd ðə wɝk tə ðɛm tə kip ðɛɹ hænz bɪzi waɪl ðeɪ weɪɾəd. ɪt sim ði eɪntʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɛɹli dɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɪntɛndɪŋ tə titʃ sʌmwʌn ə lɛsən.

Corele and Merise - almost constant attendants of Cadsuane these days - continued their embroidery in matching chairs by the hearth. Cadsuane had suggested the work to them to keep their hands busy while they waited. It seemed the ancient Aes Sedai rarely did anything without intending to teach someone a lesson.

ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ swɔɹn tə ɹænd, oʊnli bɛldaɪn wɑz ðəɹ ət ðə moʊmənt. kædzueɪn sæt nɪɹ mɪn, pɝuzɪŋ əɹ oʊn bʊk. nɪneɪiv wɔk bæk ən fɔɹθ, ʌp ən daʊn, əkeɪʒənəli tʌɡɪŋ ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd. noʊbɑdi spoʊk ə ðə tɛnʃən ɪn ðə ɹum.

Of the Aes Sedai sworn to Rand, only Beldeine was there at the moment. Cadsuane sat near Min, perusing her own book. Nynaeve walked back and forth, up and down, occasionally tugging on her braid. Nobody spoke of the tension in the room.

wʌt wɝ ɹænd ən tæm dɪskʌsɪŋ? wəd ɹændz fɑðɝ bi eɪbəl tə tɝn hɪm?

What were Rand and Tam discussing? Would Rand's father be able to turn him?

ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz kɹæmpt. wɪð θɹi tʃɛɹz ɑn ðə ɹʌɡ bɪsaɪd ðə hɑɹθ, ə bɛntʃ əlɔŋ ðə wɔl, ən nɪneɪiv kɹɔsɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹ laɪk ə spɑɾəd haʊnd, ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɹum tə muv. ðə smuð stoʊn wɔlz meɪd ðə pleɪs fil laɪk ə bɑks, ən ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn wɪndoʊ, oʊpən tə ðə naɪɾ ɛɹ, bɪhaɪn kædzueɪn. laɪt ʃoʊn fɹəm ðə koʊlz ɪn ðə hɑɹθ ən ðə læmps. ðə wɔɹɾɝz wɝ spikɪŋ ɪn loʊ toʊnz ɪn ði ədʒɔɪnɪŋ ɹum.

The chamber was cramped. With three chairs on the rug beside the hearth, a bench along the wall, and Nynaeve crossing back and forth before the door like a spotted hound, there was barely room to move. The smooth stone walls made the place feel like a box, and there was only one window, open to the night air, behind Cadsuane. Light shone from the coals in the hearth and the lamps. The Warders were speaking in low tones in the adjoining room.

jɛs, ɪt wɑz kɹæmpt, bʌt kənsɪɾɝɪŋ əɹ bænɪʃmənt, kædzueɪn wɑz lʌki tə hæv ɹumz ɪn ðə stoʊn əɾ ɔl.

Yes, it was cramped, but considering her banishment, Cadsuane was lucky to have rooms in the Stone at all.

mɪn saɪɾ ən tɝn bæk tə kɑməntɛɹi ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən. ðət seɪm fɹeɪz pɑpt aʊɾ əɾ əɹ əɡɛn. hi ʃæl hoʊld ə bleɪɾ ə laɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, ən ðə θɹi ʃæl bi wʌn. wʌɾ ɪt min?

Min sighed and turned back to Commentary on the Dragon. That same phrase popped out at her again. He shall hold a blade of light in his hands, and the three shall be one. What did it mean?

"kædzueɪn," mɪn sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ðə bʊk. "aɪ θɪŋk ði ɪntɝpɹɪteɪʃən ə ðɪs fɹeɪz ɪz ɹɔŋ."
