"Cadsuane," Min said, holding up the book. "I think the interpretation of this phrase is wrong."

əɡɛn, bɛldaɪn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə smɔl - ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɝsɛptɪbəl - snɪf ə dɪsdeɪn.

Again, Beldeine let out a small - almost imperceptible - sniff of disdain.

"ju hæv sʌmθɪŋ tə seɪ, bɛldaɪn?" kædzueɪn æskt, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm əɹ oʊn bʊk, ə hɪstɝi kɔl ðə pɹɑpɝ teɪmɪŋ ə paʊɝ.

"You have something to say, Beldeine?" Cadsuane asked, not looking up from her own book, a history called The Proper Taming of Power.

"nɑɾ ɪn soʊ mɛni wɝdz, kædzueɪn sədaɪ," bɛldaɪn ɹɪplaɪd laɪtli. ðə ɡɹin hæɾ ə feɪs ðət səm maɪɾ əv kɔl pɹɪɾi, bɛɹɪŋ tʃɹeɪsəz ə hɝ sɑldəiən hɛɹəɾədʒ. jʌŋ ɪnʌf tə nɑt jɛɾ əv ði eɪdʒləs feɪs, ʃi ɔfən sim tə tʃɹaɪ tu hɑɹd tə pɹuv hɝsɛlf.

"Not in so many words, Cadsuane Sedai," Beldeine replied lightly. The Green had a face that some might have called pretty, bearing traces of her Saldaean heritage. Young enough to not yet have the ageless face, she often seemed to try too hard to prove herself.

"ju ɑbviəsli θɔt sʌmθɪŋ wən mɪn spoʊk, bɛldaɪn," kædzueɪn ɹɪplaɪd, tɝnɪŋ ə peɪdʒ.

"You obviously thought something when Min spoke, Beldeine," Cadsuane replied, turning a page.

"aʊt wɪð ɪt."

"Out with it."

bɛldaɪn flʌʃt slaɪtli - wʌn noʊɾəst ðiz θɪŋz, ɪf wʌn spɛn ə lɑɾ ə taɪm wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Beldeine flushed slightly - one noticed these things, if one spent a lot of time with Aes Sedai.

ðeɪ dɪɾ əv ɪmoʊʃənəl ɹiækʃənz, ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌst sʌɾəl. ənlɛs, ʌv kɔɹs, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn kwɛstʃən wɑz nɪneɪiv. ɔlðoʊ ʃid ɡɹoʊn bɛɾɝ ət kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz, ʃi . . . wɛl, ʃi wɑz stɪl nɪneɪiv.

They did have emotional reactions, they were just subtle. Unless, of course, the Aes Sedai in question was Nynaeve. Although she'd grown better at controlling her emotions, she . . . well, she was still Nynaeve.

bɛldaɪn sɛd, "aɪ sɪmpli θɪŋk ðət ðə tʃaɪld ɪz əmjuzɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪ ʃi poʊks θɹu ðoʊz toʊmz, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ə skɑlɝ."

Beldeine said, "I simply think that the child is amusing in the way she pokes through those tomes, as if she were a scholar."

mɪn wʊɾə teɪkən ðəɾ əz ə tʃælənʒ fɹəm moʊs pipəl, bʌt fɹəm bɛldaɪn, ðə wɝdz wɝ mæɾɝ-ʌv-fækt.

Min would have taken that as a challenge from most people, but from Beldeine, the words were matter-of-fact.

kædzueɪn tɝn ənʌðɝ peɪdʒ. "aɪ si. mɪn, wʌt wɑz ɪt jə wɝ seɪɪŋ tə mi?"

Cadsuane turned another page. "I see. Min, what was it you were saying to me?"

"nʌθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, kædzueɪn sədaɪ."

"Nothing important, Cadsuane Sedai."

"aɪ dɪdn æsk ɪf ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ɡɝl," kædzueɪn sɛd bɹɪskli. "aɪ æsk jə tə ɹɪpit jɝsɛlf. aʊt wɪð ɪt."

"I didn't ask if it was important, girl," Cadsuane said briskly. "I asked you to repeat yourself. Out with it."

mɪn saɪd. noʊbɑdi kəd hjumɪlieɪt wʌn mɔɹ saʊnli ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, fəɹ ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪt wɪθaʊt mæləs. mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪt tə mɪn wʌns ɪn sɪmpəl tɝmz: moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ fɛlt ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ɪstæblɪʃ kəntʃɹoʊl wən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡɹeɪt kɑnflɪkt, soʊ ðəɾ ɪf ə kɹaɪsəs dɪd hæpən, pipəl wəd noʊ wɛɹ tə lʊk.

Min sighed. Nobody could humiliate one more soundly than an Aes Sedai, for they did it without malice. Moiraine had explained it to Min once in simple terms: Most Aes Sedai felt it was important to establish control when there was no great conflict, so that if a crisis did happen, people would know where to look.

ɪt wɑz vɛɹi fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ.

It was very frustrating.

"aɪ sɛd," mɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd, "ðæɾ ə pæsədʒ ɪz ɹɔŋ. ɪm ɹiɾɪŋ kɑməntɛɹi ɑn ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl. seɪdʒiɪs kleɪmz ðət ðɪs laɪn əbaʊt ðə θɹi bɪkʌmɪŋ wʌn spiks ə ðə junəfəkeɪʃən ə θɹi kɪŋdəmz bɪniθ ðə dʒɹæɡənz bænɝ. bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk hiz ɹɔŋ."

"I said," Min repeated, "that a passage is wrong. I'm reading commentary on the Karaethon Cycle. Sajius claims that this line about the three becoming one speaks of the unification of three kingdoms beneath the Dragon's banner. But I think he's wrong."

"ænd waɪ," kædzueɪn sɛd, "ɪz ɪt ðət jə θɪŋk jə noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ɹɪspɛktɪd skɑlɝ ə ðə pɹɑfəsiz?"

"And why," Cadsuane said, "is it that you think you know more than a respected scholar of the prophecies?"

"bɪkɔz," mɪn sɛd, bɹɪsəlɪŋ, "ðə θɪɹi dʌzn meɪk sɛns. ɹænd oʊnli ɹɪli hoʊlz wʌn kɹaʊn. ðəɹ maɪɾ əv bɪn ə ɡʊɾ ɑɹɡjəmən hɪɹ ɪf i hædnt ɡɪvən əweɪ tiɹ tə dɑɹlɪn. bʌt ðə θɪɹi dʌzn hoʊld ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. aɪ θɪŋk ðə pæsədʒ ɹəfɝz tə səm weɪ hiz tə juz kælændɝ."

"Because," Min said, bristling, "the theory doesn't make sense. Rand only really holds one crown. There might have been a good argument here if he hadn't given away Tear to Darlin. But the theory doesn't hold any longer. I think the passage refers to some way he has to use Callandor."

"aɪ si," kædzueɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ peɪdʒ ɪn əɹ oʊn bʊk. "ðæɾ ɪz ə vɛɹi ʌnkənvɛnʃənəl ɪntɝpɹɪteɪʃən." bɛldaɪn smaɪl θɪnli, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə hɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. "ʌv kɔɹs," kædzueɪn æɾəd, "ju ɑɹ kwaɪt ɹaɪt."

"I see," Cadsuane said, turning yet another page in her own book. "That is a very unconventional interpretation." Beldeine smiled thinly, turning back to her embroidery. "Of course," Cadsuane added, "you are quite right."

mɪn lʊkt ʌp.

Min looked up.

"ɪt wɑz ðət vɛɹi pæsədʒ ðət lɛd mi tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt kælændɝ," kædzueɪn kəntɪnjud. "θɹu ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə sɝtʃɪŋ aɪ dɪskʌvɝd ðət ðə sɔɹd kəɾ oʊnli bi juz pɹɑpɝli ɪn ə sɝkəl ə θɹi.

"It was that very passage that led me to investigate Callandor," Cadsuane continued. "Through a great deal of searching I discovered that the sword could only be used properly in a circle of three.

ðəɾ ɪz laɪkli ði ʌltəmət minɪŋ ə ðə pæsədʒ."

That is likely the ultimate meaning of the passage."

"bʌt ðət wəɾ ɪmplaɪ ðət ɹænd hæd tə juz kælændɝ ɪn ə sɝkəl sʌmtaɪm," mɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə pæsədʒ əɡɛn. hid nɛvɝ dʌn soʊ, əz fɑɹ əz ʃi nu.

"But that would imply that Rand had to use Callandor in a circle sometime," Min said, looking at the passage again. He'd never done so, as far as she knew.

"ɪt wʊd," kædzueɪn sɛd.

"It would," Cadsuane said.

mɪn fɛlt ə sʌɾən θɹɪl. ə hɪnt, pɝhæps. sʌmθɪŋ ðət ɹænd dɪdnt noʊ, ðət maɪt hɛlp hɪm!

Min felt a sudden thrill. A hint, perhaps. Something that Rand didn't know, that might help him!

ɪksɛpt . . . kædzueɪn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi noʊn ɪt. soʊ mɪn hædn dɪskʌvɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ ə ɹil ɪmpɔɹɾ æftɝ ɔl.

Except . . . Cadsuane had already known it. So Min hadn't discovered anything of real import after all.

"aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk," kædzueɪn sɛd, "ðæɾ ən æknɑlɪdʒmən ɪz du. bæd mænɝz ɑɹ nɑt tə bi tɑlɝeɪɾəd, æftɝ ɔl."

"I should think," Cadsuane said, "that an acknowledgment is due. Bad manners are not to be tolerated, after all."

bɛldaɪn lʊkt ʌp fɹəm əɹ niɾəlwɝk, feɪs dɑɹk. ðɛn, ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli, ʃi stʊɾ ən lɛf ðə ɹum. hɝ wɔɹɾɝ, ðə juθfəl æʃəmən kɑɹldɪn, fɑloʊd kwɪkli fɹəm ðə saɪd tʃeɪmbɝ, kɹɔsɪŋ ðə ɹum wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən fɑloʊɪŋ bɛldaɪn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd. kædzueɪn ɡeɪv ə snɪf, ðən tɝn bæk tə hɝ bʊk.

Beldeine looked up from her needlework, face dark. Then, unexpectedly, she stood and left the room. Her Warder, the youthful Asha'man Karldin, followed quickly from the side chamber, crossing the room with the Aes Sedai and following Beldeine out into the hallway outside. Cadsuane gave a sniff, then turned back to her book.

ðə dɔɹ kloʊzd, ən nɪneɪiv aɪd mɪn bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɝ peɪsɪŋ. mɪn kəd ɹiɾ ə lɑɾ ɪn ðət ɡlæns. nɪneɪiv wɑz ənɔɪd ðət noʊbɑdi ɛls sim nɝvəs. ʃi wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd ðət ðeɪ hædn faʊn səm weɪ tə lɪsən ɪn ɑn ɹænd ən tæmz kɑnvɝseɪʃən. ən ʃi wɑz ɑbviəsli tɛɹəfaɪd fəɹ læn. mɪn ʌndɝstʊd. ʃi fɛl sɪməlɝli əbaʊt ɹænd.

The door closed, and Nynaeve eyed Min before returning to her pacing. Min could read a lot in that glance. Nynaeve was annoyed that nobody else seemed nervous. She was frustrated that they hadn't found some way to listen in on Rand and Tam's conversation. And she was obviously terrified for Lan. Min understood. She felt similarly about Rand.

ən . . . wʌt wɑz ðət vɪʒən ðət wɑz sʌɾənli hʌvɝɪŋ əbʌv nɪneɪivz hɛd? ʃi wɑz nilɪŋ oʊvɝ sʌmwʌnz kɔɹps ɪn ə pɑstʃɝ ʌv ɡɹif. ðə vjuɪŋ wɑz ɡɔn ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ.

And . . . what was that vision that was suddenly hovering above Nynaeve's head? She was kneeling over someone's corpse in a posture of grief. The viewing was gone a moment later.

mɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ðət hædn bɪn ə vjuɪŋ ʃi kəɾ ɪntɝpɹət, soʊ ʃi lɛɾ ɪt pæs. ʃi kʊdnt weɪst əɹ taɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ənɹævəl ɔl ə ðoʊz. fəɹ ɪnstəns, ðə blæk naɪf ðət spʌn ɝaʊn bɛldaɪnz hɛd ɹisənli kəd min ɛniθɪŋ.

Min shook her head. That hadn't been a viewing she could interpret, so she let it pass. She couldn't waste her time trying to unravel all of those. For instance, the black knife that spun around Beldeine's head recently could mean anything.

ʃi foʊkəst ɑn ðə bʊk. soʊ . . . ɹænd wɑz tə juz kælændɝ əz pɑɹɾ ʌv ə sɝkəl, ðɛn? ðə θɹi bɪkʌmɪŋ wʌn? bʌt fəɹ wʌt ɹizən ən wɪð hum? ɪf i wɑz tə faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ðən ɪt dɪdn meɪk sɛns fəɹ ɪm tə bi ɪn ə sɝkəl wɪð sʌmwʌn ɛls ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl, dɪɾ ɪt?

She focused on the book. So . . . Rand was to use Callandor as part of a circle, then? The three becoming one? But for what reason and with whom? If he was to fight the Dark One, then it didn't make sense for him to be in a circle with someone else in control, did it?

"kædzueɪn," ʃi sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz stɪl ɹɔŋ. ðɛɹz mɔɹ hɪɹ. sʌmθɪŋ wi hævən dɪskʌvɝd."

"Cadsuane," she said. "This is still wrong. There's more here. Something we haven't discovered."

"əbaʊt kælændɝ?" ðə wʊmən æskt.

"About Callandor?" the woman asked.

mɪn nɑɾəd.

Min nodded.

"aɪ səspɛk soʊ əz wɛl," kædzueɪn ɹɪplaɪd. haʊ ɑd tə hɪɹ əɹ biɪŋ fɹæŋk! "bʌɾ aɪ hævən bɪn eɪbəl tə dətɝmən wʌt. ɪf oʊnli ðət ful bɔɪ wəd ɹɪvoʊk maɪ ɛɡzaɪl, wi kəd ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt - "

"I suspect so as well," Cadsuane replied. How odd to hear her being frank! "But I haven't been able to determine what. If only that fool boy would revoke my exile, we could get on with more important - "

ðə dɔɹ tə kædzueɪnz ɹum slæmd oʊpən, kɑzɪŋ mɛɹaɪs tə dʒʌmp ɪn ʃɑk. nɪneɪiv hɑp bæk fɹəm ðə dɔɹ - ɪt hæd nɪɹli hɪt hɝ.

The door to Cadsuane's room slammed open, causing Merise to jump in shock. Nynaeve hopped back from the door - it had nearly hit her.

stændɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ wɑz ə vɛɹi æŋɡɹi tæm ælθɹ. hi ɡlɛɹɾ ət kædzueɪn. "wʌɾ əv jə dʌn tə hɪm?" hi dɪmændəd.

Standing in the doorway was a very angry Tam al'Thor. He glared at Cadsuane. "What have you done to him?" he demanded.

kædzueɪn loʊɝɾ əɹ bʊk. "aɪ hæv dʌn nʌθɪŋ tə ðə bɔɪ, ʌðɝ ðən tə ɛnkɝɪdʒ ɪm təwɔɹd səvɪləɾi. sʌmθɪŋ, ɪt simz, ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ə ðə fæmli kəd lɝn əz wɛl."

Cadsuane lowered her book. "I have done nothing to the boy, other than to encourage him toward civility. Something, it seems, other members of the family could learn as well."

"wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ, ɛɛs sədaɪ," tæm snɑɹəld. "hæv jə sin hɪm? ði ɪntaɪɝ ɹum sim tə ɡɹoʊ dɑɹkɝ wən i ɛntɝd. ən ðət feɪs - aɪv sin mɔɹ ɪmoʊʃən ɪn ði aɪz ʌv ə kɔɹps! wʌɾ əz hæpən tə maɪ sʌn?"

"Watch your tongue, Aes Sedai," Tam snarled. "Have you seen him? The entire room seemed to grow darker when he entered. And that face - I've seen more emotion in the eyes of a corpse! What has happened to my son?"

"aɪ teɪk ɪt," kædzueɪn sɛd, "ðæt ðə ɹiunjən dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ əz hoʊpt?"

"I take it," Cadsuane said, "that the reunion did not go as hoped?"

tæm tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ən ði æŋɡɝ sim tə sʌɾənli floʊ aʊɾ ə hɪm. hi wɑz stɪl fɝm, hɪz aɪz dɪsplizd, bʌt ðə ɹeɪdʒ wɑz ɡɔn. mɪn hæd sin ɹænd teɪk kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɪmsɛlf ðət kwɪkli, bɪfɔɹ θɪŋz hæd stɑɹɾəd tə ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ ɪn bændɑɹ ɛbən.

Tam took a deep breath, and the anger seemed to suddenly flow out of him. He was still firm, his eyes displeased, but the rage was gone. Min had seen Rand take control of himself that quickly, before things had started to go wrong in Bandar Eban.

"hi tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mi," tæm sɛɾ ɪn ə lɛvəl vɔɪs. "maɪ oʊn sʌn. wʌns i wɑz əz dʒɛntəl ən feɪθfəl ə læɾ əz ə fɑðɝ kəd hoʊp fɔɹ. tənaɪt, hi tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən tɝn ɪɾ əɡɛns mi."

"He tried to kill me," Tam said in a level voice. "My own son. Once he was as gentle and faithful a lad as a father could hope for. Tonight, he channeled the One Power and turned it against me."

mɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ hæn tə hɝ maʊθ, filɪŋ ə pænɪk tɛɹɝ. ðə wɝdz bɹɔt bæk mɛmɹiz ə ɹænd lumɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl hɝ.

Min raised her hand to her mouth, feeling a panicked terror. The words brought back memories of Rand looming over her, trying to kill her.

bʌt ðət hædn bɪn hɪm! ɪt hæd bɪn sɛmɝhɪdʒ. hædn ɪt? oʊ, ɹænd, ʃi θɔt, ʌndɝstændɪŋ ðə peɪn ʃid fɛl θɹu ðə bɑnd. wʌɾ əv jə dʌn?

But that hadn't been him! It had been Semirhage. Hadn't it? Oh, Rand, she thought, understanding the pain she'd felt through the bond. What have you done?

"ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," kædzueɪn sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs koʊld. "æn dɪd jə spik ðə wɝdz aɪ pɹipɛɹd fəɹ ju?"

"Interesting," Cadsuane said, her voice cold. "And did you speak the words I prepared for you?"

"aɪ bɪɡæn tə," tæm sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪt wɑznt wɝkɪŋ. hi wʊdn oʊpən ʌp tə mi, ən wɛl i ʃʊdnt. ə mæn juzɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ skɹɪpt wɪð ɪz oʊn sʌn! aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə dɪd tə hɪm, wʊmən, bʌɾ aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz heɪtʃɹəd wən aɪ si ɪt. juv ə lɑt tə ɪkspleɪn tə - "

"I began to," Tam said, "but I realized that it wasn't working. He wouldn't open up to me, and well he shouldn't. A man using an Aes Sedai script with his own son! I don't know what you did to him, woman, but I recognize hatred when I see it. You have a lot to explain to - "

tæm kʌɾ ɔf əz i wɑz sʌɾənli lɪftəɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ baɪ ənsin hænz. "ju ɹikɔl, pɝhæps, wʌɾ aɪ sɛɾ əbaʊt səvɪləɾi, bɔɪ?" kædzueɪn æskt.

Tam cut off as he was suddenly lifted into the air by unseen hands. "You recall, perhaps, what I said about civility, boy?" Cadsuane asked.

"kædzueɪn!" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ju doʊnt nid tə - "

"Cadsuane!" Nynaeve said. "You don't need to - "

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt, wɪzdəm," tæm sɛd. hi lʊkt ət kædzueɪn. mɪn hæd sin əɹ tʃɹiɾ ʌðɝz laɪk ðɪs, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɹænd. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz ɡɹoʊn fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd, ən ʌðɝz ʃi dɪɾ ɪt tə wɝ pɹoʊn tə bɛloʊɪŋ.

"It's all right, Wisdom," Tam said. He looked at Cadsuane. Min had seen her treat others like this, including Rand. He had always grown frustrated, and others she did it to were prone to bellowing.

tæm stɛɹɾ əɹ ɪn ði aɪz. "aɪv noʊn mɛn hu, wən tʃælənʒd, ɔlweɪz tɝn tə ðɛɹ fɪsts fəɹ ænsɝz. aɪv nɛvɝ laɪkt ɛɛs sədaɪ; aɪ wɑz hæpi tə bi ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm wən aɪ ɹɪtɝn tə maɪ fɑɹm. ə bʊli ɪz ə bʊli, wɛðɝ ʃi juzɪz ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə hɝ ɑɹm əɹ ʌðɝ minz."

Tam stared her in the eyes. "I've known men who, when challenged, always turn to their fists for answers. I've never liked Aes Sedai; I was happy to be rid of them when I returned to my farm. A bully is a bully, whether she uses the strength of her arm or other means."

kædzueɪn snɔɹɾɪd, bʌt ðə wɝdz hæɾ ɝk hɝ, fəɹ ʃi sɛt tæm daʊn.

Cadsuane snorted, but the words had irked her, for she set Tam down.

"naʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, əz ɪf ʃid bɪn ðə wʌn tə dɪfjuz ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ, "pɝhæps wi kən ɡɛt bæk tə wʌɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. tæm ælθɹ, aɪɾ əv ɪkspɛktəd jə ʌv ɔl pipəl tə hændəl ðɪs bɛɾɝ. dɪdnt wi wɔɹn jə ðət ɹænd hæd ɡɹoʊn ənsteɪbəl?"

"Now," Nynaeve said, as if she'd been the one to defuse the exchange, "perhaps we can get back to what is important. Tam al'Thor, I'd have expected you of all people to handle this better. Didn't we warn you that Rand had grown unstable?"

"ənsteɪbəl?" tæm æskt. "nɪneɪiv, ðət bɔɪ ɪz ɹaɪt nɪɹ ɪnseɪn. wʌɾ əz hæpən tə hɪm? aɪ ʌndɝstænd wʌt bæɾəl kən də tə ə mæn, bʌt. . . ."

"Unstable?" Tam asked. "Nynaeve, that boy is right near insane. What has happened to him? I understand what battle can do to a man, but. . . ."

"ðɪs ɪz ɪɹɛləvənt," kædzueɪn sɛd. "ju ɹilaɪz, tʃaɪld, ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn əɹ læst ɑpɝtunəɾi tə seɪv jəɹ sʌn?"

"This is irrelevant," Cadsuane said. "You realize, child, that might have been our last opportunity to save your son?"

"ɪf juɾ ɪkspleɪn tə mi haʊ hi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ju," tæm sɛd, "ɪt maɪɾ əv ɡɔn dɪfɹənli. bɝn mi! ðɪs ɪz wʌɾ aɪ ɡɛt fəɹ lɪsnɪŋ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"If you'd explained to me how he regarded you," Tam said, "it might have gone differently. Burn me! This is what I get for listening to Aes Sedai."

"ðɪs ɪz wʌt jə ɡɛt fəɹ biɪŋ wʊl-hɛɾəd ən ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ wʌt jə ɑɹ toʊld!" nɪneɪiv ɪntɝdʒɛktɪd.

"This is what you get for being wool-headed and ignoring what you are told!" Nynaeve interjected.

"ðɪs ɪz wʌt wi ɔl ɡɛt," mɪn sɛd, "fɔɹ əsumɪŋ wi kən meɪk ɪm də wʌt wi wɑnt."

"This is what we all get," Min said, "for assuming we can make him do what we want."

ðə ɹum fɛl stɪl.

The room fell still.

ən sʌɾənli mɪn ɹilaɪz ðət θɹu ðɛɹ bɑnd, ʃi kəd fil ɹænd. dɪstənt, tə ðə wɛst.

And suddenly Min realized that through their bond, she could feel Rand. Distant, to the west.

"hiz ɡɔn," ʃi wɪspɝd.

"He's gone," she whispered.

"jɛs," tæm sɛd, saɪɪŋ. "hi oʊpənd wʌn ə ðoʊz ɡeɪtweɪz ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə bælkəni. lɛf mi əlaɪv, ðoʊ aɪ cʊɾə swɔɹn - lʊkɪŋ ɪn ɪz aɪz - ðəɾ i mɛn tə kɪl mi. aɪv sin ðət lʊk ɪn ði aɪz ə mɛn bɪfɔɹ, ən wʌn ə ðə tu ʌv əs ɔlweɪz ɛndəɾ ʌp bliɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ."

"Yes," Tam said, sighing. "He opened one of those gateways right on the balcony. Left me alive, though I could have sworn - looking in his eyes - that he meant to kill me. I've seen that look in the eyes of men before, and one of the two of us always ended up bleeding on the floor."

"wʌt hæpənd, ðɛn?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"What happened, then?" Nynaeve asked.

"hi . . . sim tə bi dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ sʌmθɪŋ, sʌɾənli," tæm sɛd. "hi tʊk ðət lɪɾəl stætʃu ən dæʃt θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ."

"He . . . seemed to be distracted by something, suddenly," Tam said. "He took that little statue and dashed through the gateway."

kædzueɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "æn dɪd jə si, baɪ tʃæns, wɛɹ ðət ɡeɪtweɪ tʊk hɪm?"

Cadsuane raised an eyebrow. "And did you see, by chance, where that gateway took him?"

wɛst, mɪn θɔt. fɑɹ tə ðə wɛst.

West, Min thought. Far to the west.

"aɪm nɑt sɝɾən," tæm ədmɪɾəd. "ɪt wɑz dɑɹk, ðoʊ aɪ θɔt. . . ."

"I'm not certain," Tam admitted. "It was dark, though I thought. . . ."

"wʌt?" nɪneɪiv pɹɑɾɪd.

"What?" Nynaeve prodded.

"ɛbu dɑɹ," mɪn sɛd, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ əm ɔl. "hiz ɡɔn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə sintʃæn. dʒʌst əz i toʊl ðə meɪɾənz i wʊd."

"Ebou Dar," Min said, surprising them all. "He's gone to destroy the Seanchan. Just as he told the Maidens he would."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt ðət læs pɑɹt," tæm sɛd. "bʌɾ ɪt dɪd lʊk laɪk ɛbu dɑɹ."

"I don't know about that last part," Tam said. "But it did look like Ebou Dar."

"laɪt pɹəzɝv ʌs," kɔɹəl wɪspɝd.

"Light preserve us," Corele whispered.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾinaɪn

CHAPTER 49

dʒʌst ənʌðɝ mæn ɹænd wɔkt, stʌmp ʃʌvd ɪn ðə pɑkəɾ ə hɪz koʊt, hɛd daʊn, kæɹiɪŋ ði æksɛs ki sɪkjʊɹli ɹæpt ɪn waɪt lɪnən ən lup tə hɪz bɛlt əɾ ɪz saɪd. noʊbɑdi peɪɾ ətɛnʃən tə hɪm. hi wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ mæn wɔkɪŋ ðə stʃɹits ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ. nʌθɪŋ spɛʃəl, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðəɾ i wɑz tɔlɝ ðən moʊst. hi hæd ɹɛɾɪʃ ɡoʊl hɛɹ, meɪbi sədʒɛstɪŋ səm il blʌd. bʌɾ ə lɑɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pipəl hæd flɛd tə ðə sɪɾi ɹisənli tə sik sintʃæn pɹətɛkʃən. wʌt wɑz wʌn mɔɹ?

Just Another Man Rand walked, stump shoved in the pocket of his coat, head down, carrying the access key securely wrapped in white linen and looped to his belt at his side. Nobody paid attention to him. He was just another man walking the streets of Ebou Dar. Nothing special, despite the fact that he was taller than most. He had reddish gold hair, maybe suggesting some Aiel blood. But a lot of strange people had fled to the city recently to seek Seanchan protection. What was one more?

əz lɔŋ əz ə pɝsən wɑzn eɪbəl tə tʃænəl, hi əɹ ʃi kəd faɪn stəbɪlɪɾi hɪɹ. seɪfti.

As long as a person wasn't able to channel, he or she could find stability here. Safety.

ðət bɑðɝd hɪm. ðeɪ wɝ ɪz ɛnəmiz. ðeɪ wɝ kɑŋkɝɝz. hi fɛl ðɛɹ lænz ʃʊdn bi pisfəl. ðeɪ ʃəd bi tɛɹəbəl, fʊl ə sʌfɝɪŋ kəz ə ðə tɝænɪkəl ɹul. bʌɾ ɪt wɑzn laɪk ðəɾ əɾ ɔl.

That bothered him. They were his enemies. They were conquerors. He felt their lands shouldn't be peaceful. They should be terrible, full of suffering because of the tyrannical rule. But it wasn't like that at all.

nɑɾ ənlɛs jə kəd tʃænəl. wʌt ðə sintʃæn dɪd wɪð ðɪs ɡɹup ə pipəl wɑz hɔɹəfaɪɪŋ.

Not unless you could channel. What the Seanchan did with this group of people was horrifying.

nɑɾ ɔl wɑz wɛl bɪniθ ðɪs hæpi sɝfəs. ən jɛt, ɪt wɑz ʃɑkɪŋ tə ɹilaɪz haʊ wɛl ðeɪ tʃɹiɾəd ʌðɝz.

Not all was well beneath this happy surface. And yet, it was shocking to realize how well they treated others.

tɪŋkɝz kæmpt aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi ɪn lɑɹdʒ ɡɹups. ðɛɹ wæɡənz hæd nɑt muv fəɹ wiks, ən ɪt sim ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹmɪŋ vɪlədʒəz. əz ɹænd hæd muvd əmʌŋ ðɛm, hid hɝd səm ə ðɛm spik ə sɛɾəlɪŋ daʊn. ʌðɝz hæɾ əbdʒɛktəd tə ðɪs, ʌv kɔɹs. ðeɪ wɝ ðə tɪŋkɝz, ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl.

Tinkers camped outside the city in large groups. Their wagons had not moved for weeks, and it seemed they were forming villages. As Rand had moved among them, he'd heard some of them speak of settling down. Others had objected to this, of course. They were the Tinkers, the Traveling People.

haʊ wəd ðeɪ faɪn ðə sɔŋ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sɝtʃ fəɹ ɪt? ɪt wɑz əz mʌtʃ ə pɑɹɾ ə ðɛm əz ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif.

How would they find the Song if they did not search for it? It was as much a part of them as the Way of the Leaf.

læs naɪt, ɹænd hæd lɪsən tə ðɛm ət wʌn ə ðə kæmpfaɪɝz. ðeɪd wɛlkəmd ɪm ɪn, fɛd hɪm, nɛvɝ æskɪŋ u hi wɑz. hid kɛp ðə dʒɹæɡən ɑn ɪz hæn hɪɾən ən ði æksɛs ki kɛɹfəli tʌkt ɪn ɪz koʊt pɑkət, lʊkɪŋ ət ðət faɪɝ bɝnɪŋ daʊn tə koʊlz.

Last night, Rand had listened to them at one of the campfires. They'd welcomed him in, fed him, never asking who he was. He'd kept the dragon on his hand hidden and the access key carefully tucked in his coat pocket, looking at that fire burning down to coals.

hi hædn ɛvɝ bɪn tə ɛbu dɑɹ ɪtsɛlf; hiɾ oʊnli vɪzəɾəd ðə hɪlz tə ðə nɔɹθ, wɛɹ hid fɔt ðə sintʃæn waɪl wildɪŋ kælændɝ. ðət hæd bɪn ə pleɪs ə feɪljɝ. naʊ hi hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ɔltɑɹə. bʌt fəɹ wʌt?

He hadn't ever been to Ebou Dar itself; he'd only visited the hills to the north, where he'd fought the Seanchan while wielding Callandor. That had been a place of failure. Now he had returned to Altara. But for what?

ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, wən ðə ɡeɪts tə ðə sɪɾi hæɾ oʊpənd, hi meɪɾ ɪz weɪ ɪnsaɪd wɪð ði ʌðɝz u hæɾ ɝaɪvd ət naɪt. ðə tɪŋkɝz hæd teɪkən əm ɔl ɪn; əpɛɹənli, ðeɪ wɝ ɹəsivɪŋ ə ɹæʃən ə fud fɹəm ðə sintʃæn tə haʊs æftɝ-aʊɝ tʃɹævəlɝz. ðət wɑz oʊnli wʌn ə ðɛɹ mɛni ɑkjəpeɪʃənz.

In the morning, when the gates to the city had opened, he made his way inside with the others who had arrived at night. The Tinkers had taken them all in; apparently, they were receiving a ration of food from the Seanchan to house after-hour travelers. That was only one of their many occupations.

ðeɪ mɛndɪd pɑts, soʊd junəfɔɹmz ən dɪɾ ʌðɝ ɑd dʒɑbz. fəɹ ðɪs, ðeɪ ɹəsiv ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə ɹulɝz fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn ðɛɹ lɔŋ hɪstɝi.

They mended pots, sewed uniforms and did other odd jobs. For this, they received the protection of rulers for the first time in their long history.

hid spɛn lɔŋ ɪnʌf wɪð ði il tə pɪk ʌp səm ə ðɛɹ dɪsdeɪn fəɹ ðə tɪŋkɝz. jɛt ðət dɪsdeɪn wɔɹd wɪð ɪz nɑlədʒ ðət ðə tuætɑn - ɪn mɛni weɪz - fɑloʊd mɔɹ tʃɹu, tʃɹədɪʃənəl il weɪz. ɹænd kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk tə lɪv əz ðeɪ hæd. ɪn ðə vɪʒənz ə ɹɪɾiən, hi hæd fɑloʊd ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif. hiɾ ɔlsoʊ sin ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. hid lɪv ðoʊz laɪvz, ðə laɪvz ʌv ʌðɝz, fəɹ ə fju bɹif moʊməns.

He'd spent long enough with the Aiel to pick up some of their disdain for the Tinkers. Yet that disdain warred with his knowledge that the Tuatha'an - in many ways - followed more true, traditional Aiel ways. Rand could remember what it was like to live as they had. In the visions of Rhuidean, he had followed the Way of the Leaf. He'd also seen the Age of Legends. He'd lived those lives, the lives of others, for a few brief moments.

hi wɔkt əlɔŋ ðə pæk stʃɹits ə ðə mʌɡi sɪɾi, stɪl ɪn sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə deɪz. læs naɪt, hi hæd tʃɹeɪɾɪd ɪz faɪn blæk koʊt tə ə tɪŋkɝ fəɹ ə kɑmən bɹaʊn kloʊk, ɹæɡəɾ ɑn ðə bɑɾəm ən stɪtʃt ɪn pleɪsəz. nɑɾ ə tɪŋkɝ kloʊk, dʒʌst wʌn ðəɾ ə tɪŋkɝ hæd soʊn ʌp fəɹ ə mæn u hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn tə kleɪm ɪt. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm stæn aʊt lɛs, ivən ɪf ɪt dɪd ɹikwaɪɝ ɪm tə kæɹi ði æksɛs ki lup tə hɪz bɛlt, ɹæðɝ ðən ɪz dip pɑkət. ðə tɪŋkɝ ɔlsoʊ ɡeɪv ɪm ə wɔkɪŋ stæf, wɪtʃ ɹænd juzd əz i wɔkt, slaʊtʃɪŋ slaɪtli. haɪt maɪt meɪk ɪm mɛmɝəbəl. hi wɑntəd tə bi ɪnvɪzəbəl tə ðiz pipəl.

He walked along the packed streets of the muggy city, still in something of a daze. Last night, he had traded his fine black coat to a Tinker for a common brown cloak, ragged on the bottom and stitched in places. Not a Tinker cloak, just one that a Tinker had sewn up for a man who had never returned to claim it. It made him stand out less, even if it did require him to carry the access key looped to his belt, rather than his deep pocket. The Tinker also gave him a walking staff, which Rand used as he walked, slouching slightly. Height might make him memorable. He wanted to be invisible to these people.

hi hæd nɪɹli kɪld ɪz fɑðɝ. hi hædn bɪn fɔɹs tə baɪ sɛmɝhɪdʒ, əɹ baɪ luz θɝɪnz ɪnfluəns. noʊ ɪkskjusɪz. noʊ ɑɹɡjəmənt. hi, ɹænd ælθɹ, hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ɪz oʊn fɑðɝ. hid dʒɹɔn ɪn ðə paʊɝ, meɪd ðə wivz ən nɪɹli ɹilis ðɛm.

He had nearly killed his father. He hadn't been forced to by Semirhage, or by Lews Therin's influence. No excuses. No argument. He, Rand al'Thor, had tried to kill his own father. He'd drawn in the Power, made the weaves and nearly released them.

ɹændz ɹeɪdʒ wɑz ɡɔn, ɹipleɪs baɪ loʊθɪŋ. hid wɑntəd tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf hɑɹd. hid niɾəd tə bi hɑɹd. bʌt ðɪs wɑz wɛɹ hɑɹdnəs hæd bɹɔt hɪm. luz θɝɪn hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə kleɪm mædnəs fəɹ ɪz ətʃɹɑsəɾiz. ɹænd hæd nʌθɪŋ, noʊ pleɪs tə haɪd, noʊ ɹɛfjudʒ fɹəm hɪmsɛlf.

Rand's rage was gone, replaced by loathing. He'd wanted to make himself hard. He'd needed to be hard. But this was where hardness had brought him. Lews Therin had been able to claim madness for his atrocities. Rand had nothing, no place to hide, no refuge from himself.

ɛbu dɑɹ. ɪt wɑz ə bɪzi, bʌlʒɪŋ sɪɾi, splɪɾ ɪn hæf baɪ ɪts lɑɹdʒ ɹɪvɝ. ɹænd wɔk ðə wɛst saɪd, θɹu skwɛɹz ɛdʒd wɪð bjuɾəfəl stætʃuz ən stʃɹits laɪnd wɪð ɹoʊ əpɑn ɹoʊ ʌv waɪt haʊzɪz, mɛni sɛvɹəl stɔɹiz haɪ. hi ɔfən pæs mɛn faɪɾɪŋ wɪð fɪsts əɹ naɪvz, ən noʊbɑdi meɪkɪŋ ɛni ɛfɝt tə bɹeɪk əm əpɑɹt. ivən ðə wɪmən wɔɹ naɪvz ət ðɛɹ nɛks ɪn dʒuəl skæbɝdz, hæŋɪŋ əbʌv loʊ-kʌt dʒɹɛsəz wɔɹn oʊvɝ kʌlɝfəl pɛɾikoʊts.

Ebou Dar. It was a busy, bulging city, split in half by its large river. Rand walked the west side, through squares edged with beautiful statues and streets lined with row upon row of white houses, many several stories high. He often passed men fighting with fists or knives, and nobody making any effort to break them apart. Even the women wore knives at their necks in jeweled scabbards, hanging above low-cut dresses worn over colorful petticoats.

hi ɪɡnɔɹɾ əm ɔl. ɪnstɛd, hi θɔɾ ɑn ðə tɪŋkɝz. tɪŋkɝz wɝ seɪf hɪɹ, bʌt ɹændz oʊn fɑðɝ wɑzn seɪf ɪn ɪz ɛmpaɪɝ. ɹændz fɹɛnz fɪɹd hɪm; hi hæd sin ɪɾ ɪn nɪneɪivz aɪz.

He ignored them all. Instead, he thought on the Tinkers. Tinkers were safe here, but Rand's own father wasn't safe in his empire. Rand's friends feared him; he had seen it in Nynaeve's eyes.

ðə pipəl hɪɹ wɝn əfɹeɪd. sintʃæn ɔfəsɝz muv θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz, wɛɹɪŋ ðoʊz ɪnsɛktlaɪk hɛlmz. ðə pipəl meɪd weɪ fəɹ ðɛm, bʌɾ aʊɾ ə ɹɪspɛkt. wən ɹænd hɝd kɑmənɝz spikɪŋ, ðeɪ wɝ ɡlæd fəɹ ðə stəbɪlɪɾi. ðeɪ æktʃəli  pɹeɪz ðə sintʃæn fəɹ kɑŋkɝɪŋ ðɛm!

The people here weren't afraid. Seanchan officers moved through the crowds, wearing those insectlike helms. The people made way for them, but out of respect. When Rand heard commoners speaking, they were glad for the stability. They actually praised the Seanchan for conquering them!

ɹænd kɹɔst ə ʃɔɹt, kənæl-spænɪŋ bɹɪdʒ. smɔl boʊts aɪɾəld daʊn ðə wɔɾɝweɪ, boʊtmən kɔlɪŋ ɡɹiɾɪŋz tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðəɹ dɪdn sim tə bi ɛni sɛns ʌv ɔɹɾɝ tə ðə sɪɾi leɪaʊt; wɛɹ i ɪkspɛktəd haʊsəz, hi faʊnd ʃɑps, ən ɪnstɛɾ ə sɪməlɝ ʃɑps klʌstɝɪŋ təɡɛðɝ -  əz wɑz kɑmən ɪn moʊst sɪɾiz - hɪɹ ðeɪ wɝ skæɾɝd, hæphæzɝd. ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə bɹɪdʒ, hi pæst ə tɔl, waɪt mænʃən, ðən ə tævɝn ɹaɪt nɛks tə ɪt.

Rand crossed a short, canal-spanning bridge. Small boats idled down the waterway, boatmen calling greetings to one another. There didn't seem to be any sense of order to the city layout; where he expected houses, he found shops, and instead of similar shops clustering together -  as was common in most cities - here they were scattered, haphazard. On the other side of the bridge, he passed a tall, white mansion, then a tavern right next to it.

ə mæn ɪn ə kʌlɝfəl sɪlk vɛs dʒɑsəld ɹænd ɑn ðə stʃɹit, ðən ɔfɝɾ ə lɛŋθi, oʊvɝli pəlaɪɾ əpɑlədʒi. ɹænd hɝiɾ ɑn, lɛs ðə mæn wɑnə stɑɹɾ ə duəl.

A man in a colorful silk vest jostled Rand on the street, then offered a lengthy, overly polite apology. Rand hurried on, lest the man want to start a duel.

ðɪs dɪd nɑt sim laɪk ən əpɹɛs pipəl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌndɝkɝən ə ɹɪzɛnmənt. ðə sintʃæn hæɾ ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ hoʊld ɑn ɛbu dɑɹ ðən ɹænd hæɾ ɑn bændɑɹ ɛbən, ən ðə pipəl hɪɹ wɝ hæpi - ivən pɹɑspɝəs! ʌv kɔɹs, ɔltɑɹə - əz ə kɪŋdəm - hæd nɛvɝ bɪn vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ. ɹænd nu fɹəm ɪz tuɾɝz ðət ðə kɹaʊnz əθɔɹəɾi hædn ɪkstɛndəd mʌtʃ bɪɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝz ə ðə sɪɾi.

This did not seem like an oppressed people. There was no undercurrent of resentment. The Seanchan had a much better hold on Ebou Dar than Rand had on Bandar Eban, and the people here were happy - even prosperous! Of course, Altara - as a kingdom - had never been very strong. Rand knew from his tutors that the Crown's authority hadn't extended much beyond the borders of the city.

ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ ðə seɪm fəɹ ði ʌðɝ pleɪsəz ðə sintʃæn hæd kɑŋkɝd. tæɹɑbən, ɑmɑdɪʃiə, ɑlməθ pleɪn. səm wɝ mɔɹ steɪbəl ðən ɔltɑɹə, ʌðɝz lɛs, bʌɾ ɔl wəd wɛlkəm sɪkjʊɹəɾi.

It was much the same for the other places the Seanchan had conquered. Tarabon, Amadicia, Almoth Plain. Some were more stable than Altara, others less, but all would welcome security.

ɹænd stɑpt ən lin əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ waɪt bɪldɪŋ, ðɪs wʌn ə fɛɹiɝz ʃɑp. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz stʌmp tə hɪz hɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə klɪɹ ɪz maɪnd.

Rand stopped and leaned against another white building, this one a farrier's shop. He raised his stump to his head, trying to clear his mind.

hi dɪdnt wɑnə kənfɹʌnt wʌɾ i hæd nɪɹli dʌn bæk ɪn ðə stoʊn. hi dɪdnt wɑnə kənfɹʌnt wʌɾ i hæd dʌn: wivɪŋ ɛɹ ən ʃʌvɪŋ tæm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, θɹɛɾənɪŋ hɪm; ɹeɪvɪŋ.

He didn't want to confront what he had nearly done back in the Stone. He didn't want to confront what he had done: weaving Air and shoving Tam to the ground, threatening him; raving.

ɹænd kʊdn foʊkəs ɑn ðæt. hi hæd nɑt kʌm tə ɛbu dɑɹ tə ɡɔk laɪk ə fɑɹmbɔɪ. hi hæd kʌm tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪz ɛnəmiz! ðeɪ dɪfaɪd hɪm; ðeɪ niɾəd tə bi ɪlɪməneɪɾəd. fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ʌv ɔl neɪʃənz.

Rand couldn't focus on that. He had not come to Ebou Dar to gawk like a farmboy. He had come to destroy his enemies! They defied him; they needed to be eliminated. For the good of all nations.

bʌɾ ɪf i dʒɹu ðət mʌtʃ paʊɝ θɹu ði æksɛs ki, wʌt dæmədʒ wəɾ i kɑz? haʊ mɛni laɪvz wəɾ i ɛnd? ən wəɾ i nɑt sɪmpli laɪɾ ə bikən fəɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən, əz i hæɾ ɪn klɛnzɪŋ seɪɾɪn?

But if he drew that much power through the access key, what damage would he cause? How many lives would he end? And would he not simply light a beacon for the Forsaken, as he had in cleansing saidin?

lɛɾ əm kʌm. hi stʃɹeɪɾənd ʌp. hi kəd dɪfit ðɛm.

Let them come. He straightened up. He could defeat them.

ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ətæk. taɪm tə bɝn ðə sintʃæn ɔf ðə lænd. hi sɛɾ əsaɪɾ ɪz stæf ən tʊk ðə ki ɔf ɪts stʃɹæp əɾ ɪz bɛlt, bʌt kəd nɑt fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə ənɹæp ɪt fɹəm ɪts lɪnən ʃɹaʊd. hi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪɾ ɪn ɪz hæn fəɹ ə taɪm, ðən kəntɪnjud tə wɔk, aɪdli livɪŋ ðə stæf bɪhaɪnd. ɪt fɛl soʊ ɑd tə bi dʒʌst ənʌðɝ fɔɹənɝ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɔkt əmʌŋ ðɪs pipəl, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ hɪm. tə ðɛm, ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz fɑɹ ɔf. ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz sɛkəndɛɹi tə wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðeɪ kəd ɡɛt ðɛɹ tʃɪkənz tə mɑɹkət, əɹ wɛðɝ ðɛɹ sʌn wəd ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹəm ɪz kɑf, əɹ wɛðɝ ðeɪ wəd bi eɪbəl tə əfɔɹd ðət nu sɪlk vɛs ðeɪ hæd bɪn wɑntɪŋ.

It was time to attack. Time to burn the Seanchan off the land. He set aside his staff and took the key off its strap at his belt, but could not force himself to unwrap it from its linen shroud. He stared at it in his hand for a time, then continued to walk, idly leaving the staff behind. It felt so odd to be just another foreigner. The Dragon Reborn walked among this people, and they did not know him. To them, Rand al'Thor was far off. The Last Battle was secondary to whether or not they could get their chickens to market, or whether their son would recover from his cough, or whether they would be able to afford that new silk vest they had been wanting.

ðeɪ wəd nɑt noʊ ɹænd əntɪl i dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðɛm.

They would not know Rand until he destroyed them.

ɪɾəl bi ə mɝsi, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. dɛθ ɪz ɔlweɪz ə mɝsi. ðə mædmæn dɪdn saʊn əz kɹeɪzi əz i wʌns hæd. ɪn fækt, hɪz vɔɪs hæd stɑɹɾəd tə saʊn ən ɑfəl lɑt laɪk ɹændz oʊn vɔɪs.

It will be a mercy, Lews Therin whispered. Death is always a mercy. The madman didn't sound as crazy as he once had. In fact, his voice had started to sound an awful lot like Rand's own voice.

ɹænd stɑpt ətɑp ənʌðɝ bɹɪdʒ, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ət ðə sɪɾiz mæsɪv waɪt-wɔl pæləs, hoʊm tə ðə sintʃæn kɔɹt. ɪt ɹoʊz fɔɹ stɔɹiz haɪ, wɪð ɹɪŋz ʌv ɡoʊld ət ðə beɪs ʌv ɪts fɔɹ doʊmz ən mɔɹ ɡoʊld ət ðə tɪps ʌv ɪts mɛni spaɪɹz. ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz wəd bi faʊn ɪn ðɛɹ. hi kəd ɡɪv ðoʊz wɔlz ə pjʊɹəɾi ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ noʊn, ə pɝfɛkʃən. ðət wəd meɪk ðə bɪldɪŋ kəmplit, ɪn ə weɪ, ɪn ðə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ ɪt feɪɾəd ɪndə nʌθɪŋnəs.

Rand stopped atop another bridge, looking over at the city's massive white-walled palace, home to the Seanchan court. It rose four stories high, with rings of gold at the base of its four domes and more gold at the tips of its many spires. The Daughter of the Nine Moons would be found in there. He could give those walls a purity they had never known, a perfection. That would make the building complete, in a way, in the moment before it faded into nothingness.

hi ənɹæp ði æksɛs ki, dʒʌst ənʌðɝ fɔɹənɝ, stændɪŋ ɑn ðə mʌɾi bɹɪdʒ. æftɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ðə pæləs, hi wəɾ əv tə bi kwɪk. hid sɛn ɔf bɝsts ə bɑlfaɪɝ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə ʃɪps ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ, ðən juz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ məndeɪn tə ɹeɪn faɪɝ ɑn ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf, θɹoʊ ɪɾ ɪndə ə pænɪk.

He unwrapped the access key, just another foreigner, standing on the muddy bridge. After destroying the palace, he would have to be quick. He'd send off bursts of balefire to destroy the ships in the harbor, then use something more mundane to rain fire on the city itself, throw it into a panic.

ðə keɪɑs wəd dɪleɪ hɪz ɛnəmiz' ɹiækʃən. æftɝ ðæt, hi wəd tʃɹævəl tə ðə ɡæɹɪsənz ət ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts ən dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm. hi veɪɡli ɹɪmɛmbɝd skaʊt ɹɪpɔɹts ə səplaɪ kæmps tə ðə nɔɹθ, wɛl stɑkt wɪð boʊθ soʊlʒɝz ən fudstʌfs. hi wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm nɛkst.

The chaos would delay his enemies' reaction. After that, he would Travel to the garrisons at the city gates and destroy them. He vaguely remembered scout reports of supply camps to the north, well stocked with both soldiers and foodstuffs. He would destroy them next.

fɹəm ðɛɹ, hid nid tə muv ɑn tə æmədɔɹ, ðən tə tæntʃəkoʊ ən ʌðɝz. hid tʃɹævəl kwɪkli, nɛvɝ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɪn wʌn pleɪs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bi kɑt baɪ ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ə flɪkɝɪŋ laɪɾ ə dɛθ, laɪk ə bɝnɪŋ ɪmbɝ, flɛɹɪŋ tə laɪf hɪɹ, ðən ðɛɹ. mɛni wəd daɪ, bʌt moʊst wəd bi sintʃæn.

From there, he'd need to move on to Amador, then to Tanchico and others. He'd Travel quickly, never remaining in one place long enough to be caught by the Forsaken. A flickering light of death, like a burning ember, flaring to life here, then there. Many would die, but most would be Seanchan.

ɪnveɪɾɝz.

Invaders.

hi stɛɹd daʊn ət ði æksɛs ki. ðən i siz seɪɾɪn.

He stared down at the access key. Then he seized saidin.

ðə sɪknəs wɑʃt əkɹɔs ɪm mɔɹ paʊɝfli ðən ɪɾ ɛvɝ hæd bɪfɔɹ. ðə fɔɹs ʌv ɪt nɑkt ɪm tə ðə ɡɹaʊn laɪk ə fɪzɪkəl bloʊ. hi kɹaɪɾ aʊt, bɛɹli noʊɾɪsɪŋ wən i hɪt ðə stoʊnz. hi ɡɹoʊnd, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ði æksɛs ki, kɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪt. hɪz ɪnsaɪdz sim tə bɝn, ən i tɝn ɪz hɛd, ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑntu hɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən vɑməɾɪŋ ɑntu ðə bɹɪdʒ.

The sickness washed across him more powerfully than it ever had before. The force of it knocked him to the ground like a physical blow. He cried out, barely noticing when he hit the stones. He groaned, gripping the access key, curling around it. His insides seemed to burn, and he turned his head, rolling onto his shoulder and vomiting onto the bridge.

bʌɾ i hɛld ɑn tə seɪɾɪn. hi niɾəd ðə paʊɝ. ðə sʌkjəlɪnt, bjuɾəfəl paʊɝ. ivən ðə stɛntʃ ə hɪz oʊn vɑmət simd mɔɹ ɹil tə hɪm, mɔɹ swit, fəɹ ðə paʊɝ wɪðɪn hɪm.

But he held on to saidin. He needed the power. The succulent, beautiful power. Even the stench of his own vomit seemed more real to him, more sweet, for the power within him.

hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz. pipəl wɝ ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, kənsɝnd. eɪ sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊl wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ. naʊ wɑz ðə taɪm. hi hæd tə stʃɹaɪk.

He opened his eyes. People were gathered around him, concerned. A Seanchan patrol was approaching. Now was the time. He had to strike.

bʌɾ i kəd nɑt. ðə pipəl lʊk soʊ kənsɝnd. soʊ wɝid. ðeɪ kɛɹd.

But he could not. The people looked so concerned. So worried. They cared.

skɹimɪŋ ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, ɹænd meɪɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ, kɑzɪŋ ðə pipəl tə dʒʌmp bæk ɪn ʃɑk. hi stʌmbəl tə hɪz fiɾ ən θɹu hɪmsɛlf θɹu, skɹæbəlɪŋ ɑn ɔl fɔɹz, əz ðə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz dʒɹu sɔɹdz ən jɛld ʌnfəmɪljɝ wɝdz.

Screaming in frustration, Rand made a gateway, causing the people to jump back in shock. He stumbled to his feet and threw himself through, scrabbling on all fours, as the Seanchan soldiers drew swords and yelled unfamiliar words.

ɹænd lændəɾ ɑn ə lɑɹdʒ stoʊn dɪsk ə blæk ən waɪt, ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn ɪm ə vɔɪɾ ə dɑɹknəs. ðə pɔɹɾəl kloʊz bɪhaɪnd, lɑkɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹ əweɪ, ən ðə dɪsk bɪɡæn tə muv. ɪt floʊɾəd θɹu ðə vɔɪd, lɪt baɪ səm stʃɹeɪnʒ æmbiən laɪt. ɹænd kɝld ʌp ɑn ðə dɪsk, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ði æksɛs ki, bɹiðɪŋ dipli.

Rand landed on a large stone disc of black and white, the air around him a void of darkness. The portal closed behind, locking Ebou Dar away, and the disc began to move. It floated through the void, lit by some strange ambient light. Rand curled up on the disc, cradling the access key, breathing deeply.

waɪ kæn aɪ bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf? hi dɪdnt noʊ ɪf ðə θɔt wɑz ɪz əɹ ɪf ɪt wɑz luz θɝɪnz.

Why can't I be strong enough? He didn't know if the thought was his or if it was Lews Therin's.

ðə tu wɝ ðə seɪm. waɪ kæn aɪ də wʌɾ aɪ mʌst?

The two were the same. Why can't I do what I must?

ðə dɪsk tʃɹævəl fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm, ði oʊnli saʊn ɪn ðə vɔɪd ðəɾ ə hɪz bɹiðɪŋ. ðə dɪsk lʊk laɪk wʌn ə ðə silz tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, splɪt wɪð ə sɪnwəs laɪn dɪvaɪɾɪŋ ðə blæk fɹəm ðə waɪt. ɹænd leɪ dɝɛkli ətɑp ɪt. ðeɪ kɔl ðə blæk hæf ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ. tə ðə pipəl, ɪt sɪmbəlaɪzd ivəl. dɪstʃɹʌkʃən.

The disc traveled for a short time, the only sound in the void that of his breathing. The disc looked like one of the seals to the Dark One's prison, split with a sinuous line dividing the black from the white. Rand lay directly atop it. They called the black half the Dragon's Fang. To the people, it symbolized evil. Destruction.

bʌt ɹænd wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. waɪ hæd ðə pæɾɝn pʊʃt ɪm soʊ hɑɹɾ ɪf i dɪdnt nid tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ? ɝɪdʒənəli, hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə əvɔɪd kɪlɪŋ - bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn lɪɾəl tʃæns ə ðət wɝkɪŋ.

But Rand was necessary destruction. Why had the Pattern pushed him so hard if he didn't need to destroy? Originally, he had tried to avoid killing - but there had been little chance of that working.

ðən hid meɪd hɪmsɛlf əvɔɪd kɪlɪŋ wɪmən. ðət hæd pɹuvən ɪmpɑsəbəl.

Then he'd made himself avoid killing women. That had proven impossible.

hi wɑz dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. hi dʒʌs hæd tə æksɛp ðæt. sʌmwʌn hæd tə bi hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə də wʌt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, dɪdn ðeɪ?

He was destruction. He just had to accept that. Someone had to be hard enough to do what was necessary, didn't they?

ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpənd, ən i stʌmbəl tə hɪz fit, klʌtʃɪŋ ði æksɛs ki. hi stɛp fɹəm ðə skɪmɪŋ plætfɔɹm ən aʊɾ ɑntu ən ɛmpti mɛdoʊ. ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hid fɔt ðə sintʃæn wʌns wɪð kælændɝ. ən feɪld.

A gateway opened, and he stumbled to his feet, clutching the access key. He stepped from the Skimming platform and out onto an empty meadow. The place where he'd fought the Seanchan once with Callandor. And failed.

hi stɛɹɾ ət ðɪs pleɪs fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, bɹiðɪŋ ɪn ən aʊt, ðən spʌn ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ. ðɪs wʌn oʊpən ɑntu ə fild ə snoʊ, ən aɪsi wɪn blæstəɾ ət hɪm. hi stɛp θɹu, fit kɹʌntʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə snoʊ, ən lɛt ðə ɡeɪtweɪ kloʊs.

He stared at this place for a long time, breathing in and out, then spun another gateway. This one opened onto a field of snow, and icy wind blasted at him. He stepped through, feet crunching into the snow, and let the gateway close.

hɪɹ, ðə wɝl spɹɛd bɪfɔɹ hɪm.

Here, the world spread before him.

waɪ hæv wi kʌm hɪɹ? ɹænd θɔt.

Why have we come here? Rand thought.

bɪkɔz, ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd. kəz wi meɪd ðɪs. ðɪs ɪz wɛɹ wi daɪd.

Because, Rand replied. Because we made this. This is where we died.

hi stʊɾ ɑn ðə vɛɹi pɔɪn ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, ðə loʊn pik ðət hæɾ ɪɹʌptəd wɛɹ luz θɝɪn hæd kɪl hɪmsɛlf θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ. tə wʌn saɪd, hi kəd si daʊn hʌnʒɹədz ə fit tə wɛɹ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə maʊntən oʊpən ɪndə ə blæstəd-aʊt kæzəm. ði oʊpənɪŋ wɑz ɪnɔɹməs, lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ɪt lʊk fɹəm pɹoʊfaɪl. ə waɪɾ oʊvəl ə ɹɛd, bleɪzɪŋ, tʃɝnɪŋ ɹɑk. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ə tʃʌŋk ə ðə maʊntən wɝ sɪmpli mɪsɪŋ, tɔɹn əweɪ, livɪŋ ðə pik tə ɹaɪz ɪndə ði ɛɹ bʌt ði ɪntaɪɝ saɪɾ ə ðə maʊntən ɡɔn.

He stood on the very point of Dragonmount, the lone peak that had erupted where Lews Therin had killed himself three thousand years before. To one side, he could see down hundreds of feet to where the side of the mountain opened into a blasted-out chasm. The opening was enormous, larger than it looked from profile. A wide oval of red, blazing, churning rock. It was as if a chunk of the mountain were simply missing, torn away, leaving the peak to rise into the air but the entire side of the mountain gone.

ɹænd stɛɹd daʊn ɪndə ðət siθɪŋ kæzəm. ɪt wɑz laɪk ðə mɔ ʌv ə bist. hit bɝn fɹəm bɪloʊ ən fleɪks ʌv æʃ twɪstəɾ ɪndə ðə skaɪ.

Rand stared down into that seething chasm. It was like the maw of a beast. Heat burned from below and flakes of ash twisted into the sky.

ðə dʌn skaɪ wɑz klaʊɾəd əbʌv hɪm. ðə ɡɹaʊn simd ikwəli dɪstənt, bɛɹli vɪzəbəl, laɪk ə kwɪl mɑɹkt wɪð pæɾɝnz. hɪɹ ə pætʃ ʌv ɡɹin ðət wɑz ə fɔɹəst. ðəɹ ə stɪtʃ ðət wɑz ə ɹɪvɝ. tə ði ist, hi sɔ ə smɔl spɛk ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ, laɪk ə floʊɾɪŋ lif kɑɾ ɪn ðə taɪni kɝənt. tɑɹ vəlɑn.

The dun sky was clouded above him. The ground seemed equally distant, barely visible, like a quilt marked with patterns. Here a patch of green that was a forest. There a stitch that was a river. To the east, he saw a small speck in the river, like a floating leaf caught in the tiny current. Tar Valon.

ɹænd sæt daʊn, ðə snoʊ kɹʌntʃɪŋ bɪniθ ɪz weɪt. hi sɛt ði æksɛs ki ɪndə ðə bæŋk bɪfɔɹ ɪm ən woʊv ɛɹ ən faɪɝ tə kip hɪmsɛlf wɔɹm.

Rand sat down, the snow crunching beneath his weight. He set the access key into the bank before him and wove Air and Fire to keep himself warm.

ðən i ɹɛstəɾ ɪz ɛlboʊz ɑn ɪz niz ən ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ɪz hænd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv stætʃu ʌv ðə mæn wɪð ðə ɡloʊb.

Then he rested his elbows on his knees and his head on his hand, staring at the diminutive statue of the man with the globe.

tə θɪŋk.

To think.

tʃæptɝ fɪfti

CHAPTER 50

veɪnz ʌv ɡoʊld wɪn blu ɝaʊn ɹænd əz i sæɾ ət ðə tɑp ə ðə wɝld. hɪz wivɪŋ ʌv ɛɹ ən faɪɝ hæd mɛltəɾ əweɪ ðə snoʊ ɝaʊn hɪm, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ə dʒæɡd ɡɹeɪ-blæk tɪp ə ɹɑk əbaʊt θɹi peɪsɪz waɪd. ðə pik wɑz laɪk ə bɹoʊkən fɪŋɡɝneɪl dʒʌɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə skaɪ, ən ɹænd sæɾ ətɑp ɪt. əz fɑɹ əz i kəd tɛl, ɪt wɑz ðə vɛɹi tɪp ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. pɝhæps ðə haɪəs pɔɪn ɪn ðə wɝld.

Veins of Gold Wind blew around Rand as he sat at the top of the world. His weaving of Air and Fire had melted away the snow around him, exposing a jagged gray-black tip of rock about three paces wide. The peak was like a broken fingernail jutting into the sky, and Rand sat atop it. As far as he could tell, it was the very tip of Dragonmount. Perhaps the highest point in the world.

hi sæɾ əpɑn ɪz smɔl aʊtkɹɑpɪŋ, ði æksɛs ki sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹɑk ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ði ɛɹ wɑz θɪn hɪɹ, ən hid hæd tʃɹʌbəl bɹiðɪŋ əntɪl hid faʊn ə weɪ tə wiv ɛɹ soʊ ðəɾ ɪt kəmpɹɛst slaɪtli ɝaʊn hɪm. laɪk ðə wiv ðət wɔɹm hɪm, hi wɑzn sɝɾən haʊ hid dʌn ɪt. hi veɪɡli ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ æzmɑɾiən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə titʃ ɪm ə sɪməlɝ wiv, ən ɹænd hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ ɪt ɹaɪt.

He sat upon his small outcropping, the access key sitting on the rock in front of him. The air was thin here, and he'd had trouble breathing until he'd found a way to weave Air so that it compressed slightly around him. Like the weave that warmed him, he wasn't certain how he'd done it. He vaguely remembered Asmodean trying to teach him a similar weave, and Rand hadn't been able to get it right.

naʊ ɪt keɪm nætʃɹəli. luz θɝɪnz ɪnfluəns, əɹ ɪz oʊn ɡɹoʊɪŋ fəmɪljɛɹəɾi wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ?

Now it came naturally. Lews Therin's influence, or his own growing familiarity with the One Power?

dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊns bɹoʊkən, oʊpən maʊθ leɪ sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd fit bɪniθ hɪm, tə ðə lɛft. ðə sɛns ʌv æʃ ən sʌlfɝ wɝ pʌnʒənt, ivən ət ðɪs dɪstəns. ðə mɔ wɑz blæk wɪð æʃ ən ɹɛd fɹəm moʊltən ɹɑk ən bleɪzɪŋ faɪɝz.

Dragonmount's broken, open mouth lay several hundred feet beneath him, to the left. The scents of ash and sulphur were pungent, even at this distance. The maw was black with ash and red from molten rock and blazing fires.

hi stɪl hɛl tə ðə sɔɹs. hi dɪdn dɛɹ lɛt ɡoʊ. ðɪs læs taɪm hid sizd ɪt hæd bɪn ðə wɝst i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən i fɪɹd ðət ðə sɪknəs wəɾ oʊvɝpaʊɝ ɪm ɪf i tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn.

He still held to the Source. He didn't dare let go. This last time he'd seized it had been the worst he could remember, and he feared that the sickness would overpower him if he tried again.

hi hæd bɪn hɪɹ fəɹ aʊɝz. ən jɛɾ i dɪd nɑt fil taɪɝd. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. θɪŋkɪŋ.

He had been here for hours. And yet he did not feel tired. He stared at the ter'angreal. Thinking.

wʌt wɑz hi? wʌt wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? ə sɪmbəl? ə sækɹəfaɪs? ə sɔɹd, mɛn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ?

What was he? What was the Dragon Reborn? A symbol? A sacrifice? A sword, meant to destroy?

ə ʃɛltɝɪŋ hænd, mɛn tə pɹətɛkt?

A sheltering hand, meant to protect?

ə pʌpət, pleɪɪŋ ə pɑɹɾ oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ əɡɛn?

A puppet, playing a part over and over again?

hi wɑz æŋɡɹi. æŋɡɹi ət ðə wɝld, æŋɡɹi ət ðə pæɾɝn, æŋɡɹi ət ðə kɹieɪɾɝ fəɹ livɪŋ hjumənz tə faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪð noʊ dɝɛkʃən. wʌt ɹaɪt dɪɾ ɛni ʌv əm əv tə dɪmæn ɹændz laɪf ə hɪm?

He was angry. Angry at the world, angry at the Pattern, angry at the Creator for leaving humans to fight against the Dark One with no direction. What right did any of them have to demand Rand's life of him?

wɛl, ɹænd hæɾ ɔfɝd ðət laɪf tə ðɛm. ɪt hæd teɪkən ɪm ə ɡɹeɪt waɪl tə æksɛpt ɪz dɛθ, bʌɾ i hæd meɪɾ ɪz pis. wɑzn ðəɾ ɪnʌf? dɪɾ i hæv tə bi ɪn peɪn əntɪl ði ɛnd?

Well, Rand had offered that life to them. It had taken him a great while to accept his death, but he had made his peace. Wasn't that enough? Did he have to be in pain until the end?

hi hæd θɔt ðəɾ ɪf i meɪd hɪmsɛlf hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf, ɪt wəd teɪk əweɪ ðə peɪn. ɪf i kʊdn fil, ðən i kʊdn hɝt.

He had thought that if he made himself hard enough, it would take away the pain. If he couldn't feel, then he couldn't hurt.

ðə wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd pʌlsd ɪn æɡəni. fəɹ ə taɪm, hid bɪn eɪbəl tə fɝɡɛt ðɛm. bʌt ðə dɛθs i hæd kɑzd ɹʌbd ɪz soʊl ɹɔ. ðət lɪst stɑɹɾɪŋ wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd bɪɡʌn tə ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ əɾ əɹ dɛθ. bɪfɔɹ ðæt, hid stɪl hæd hoʊp.

The wounds in his side pulsed in agony. For a time, he'd been able to forget them. But the deaths he had caused rubbed his soul raw. That list starting with Moiraine. Everything had begun to go wrong at her death. Before that, he'd still had hope.

bɪfɔɹ ðæt, hid nɛvɝ bɪn pʊɾ ɪn ə bɑks.

Before that, he'd never been put in a box.

hi ʌndɝstʊd wʌt wəd bi ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə hɪm, ən hid tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ðə weɪz i θɔɾ i niɾəd. ðoʊz tʃeɪnʒəz wɝ tə kip ɪm fɹəm biɪŋ oʊvɝwɛlmd. daɪ tə pɹətɛk pipəl i dɪdnt noʊ? tʃoʊzən tə seɪv mænkaɪnd? tʃoʊzən tə fɔɹs ðə kɪŋdəmz ə ðə wɝl tə junaɪt bɪhaɪn hɪm, dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ðoʊz u ɹəfjuz tə lɪsən? tʃoʊzən tə kɑz ðə dɛθs ə θaʊzənz u fɔɾ ɪn ɪz neɪm, tə hoʊl ðoʊz soʊlz əpɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ə weɪt ðət mʌs bi bɔɹn? wʌt mæn kəd də ðiz θɪŋz ən ɹɪmeɪn seɪn? ði oʊnli weɪ hi hæd sin hæd bɪn tə kʌɾ ɔf ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz, tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf kwəndɪlɝ.

He understood what would be required of him, and he'd changed in the ways he thought he needed. Those changes were to keep him from being overwhelmed. Die to protect people he didn't know? Chosen to save mankind? Chosen to force the kingdoms of the world to unite behind him, destroying those who refused to listen? Chosen to cause the deaths of thousands who fought in his name, to hold those souls upon his shoulders, a weight that must be borne? What man could do these things and remain sane? The only way he had seen had been to cut off his emotions, to make himself cuendillar.

bʌɾ i hæd feɪld. hi hædn bɪn eɪbəl tə stæmp ɪz filɪŋz aʊt. ðə vɔɪs ɪnsaɪd hæd bɪn soʊ smɔl, bʌɾ ɪt hæd pɹɪkt ət hɪm, laɪk ə niɾəl meɪkɪŋ ðə smɔləst ə hoʊlz ɪn ɪz hɑɹt. ivən ðə smɔləst ə hoʊlz wəd lɛt ðə blʌd lik fɹi.

But he had failed. He hadn't been able to stamp his feelings out. The voice inside had been so small, but it had pricked at him, like a needle making the smallest of holes in his heart. Even the smallest of holes would let the blood leak free.

ðoʊz hoʊlz wəd bliɾ ɪm dʒɹaɪ.

Those holes would bleed him dry.

ðə kwaɪət vɔɪs wɑz ɡɔn naʊ. ɪt hæd vænɪʃt wən hid θɹoʊn tæm tə ðə flɔɹ ən nɪɹli kɪl hɪm. wɪθaʊt ðət vɔɪs, dɪd ɹænd dɛɹ kəntɪnju? ɪf ɪt wɑz ðə læst ɹɛmnən ə ði oʊld ɹænd - ðə ɹænd u hæd bɪliv ðəɾ i nu wʌt wɑz ɹaɪɾ ən wʌt wɑz ɹɔŋ - ðən wʌɾ ɪts saɪləns min?

The quiet voice was gone now. It had vanished when he'd thrown Tam to the floor and nearly killed him. Without that voice, did Rand dare continue? If it was the last remnant of the old Rand - the Rand who had believed that he knew what was right and what was wrong - then what did its silence mean?

ɹænd pɪkt ʌp ði æksɛs ki ən stʊɾ ʌp, buts skɹeɪpɪŋ stoʊn. ɪt wɑz mɪddeɪ, ðoʊ ðə sʌn stɪl leɪ hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ðə klaʊdz. bɪloʊ, hi kəd si hɪlz ən fɔɹəsts, leɪks ən vɪlədʒəz.

Rand picked up the access key and stood up, boots scraping stone. It was midday, though the sun still lay hidden behind the clouds. Below, he could see hills and forests, lakes and villages.

"ænd wʌɾ ɪf aɪ doʊnt wɑn ðə pæɾɝn tə kəntɪnju?" hi bɛloʊd. hi stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ɹaɪt tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹɑk, klʌtʃɪŋ ði æksɛs ki tə hɪz tʃɛst.

"And what if I don't want the Pattern to continue?" he bellowed. He stepped forward, right to the edge of the rock, clutching the access key to his chest.

"wi lɪv ðə seɪm laɪvz!" hi jɛld ət ðɛm. "oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ. wi meɪk ðə seɪm mɪsteɪks. kɪŋdəmz də ðə seɪm stupəd θɪŋz. ɹulɝz feɪl ðɛɹ pipəl taɪm ən taɪm əɡɛn. mɛn kəntɪnju tə hɝɾ ən heɪɾ ən daɪ ən kɪl!"

"We live the same lives!" he yelled at them. "Over and over and over. We make the same mistakes. Kingdoms do the same stupid things. Rulers fail their people time and time again. Men continue to hurt and hate and die and kill!"

wɪnz bəfeɪd hɪm, wɪpɪŋ əɾ ɪz bɹaʊn kloʊk ən ɪz faɪn tɛɹən tʃɹaʊzɝz. bʌɾ ɪz wɝdz kæɹid, ɛkoʊɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə bɹoʊkən ɹɑks ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. ɪt wɑz koʊld ən kɹɪsp, ði ɛɹ nu. hɪz wiv kɛpt ɪm wɔɹm ɪnʌf tə sɝvaɪv, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt stɑp ðə tʃɪl. hi hædnt wɑntəɾ ɪt tə.

Winds buffeted him, whipping at his brown cloak and his fine Tairen trousers. But his words carried, echoing across the broken rocks of Dragonmount. It was cold and crisp, the air new. His weave kept him warm enough to survive, but it did not stop the chill. He hadn't wanted it to.

"wʌɾ ɪf aɪ θɪŋk ɪts ɔl minɪŋləs?" hi dɪmændəd wɪð ðə laʊd vɔɪs ʌv ə kɪŋ. "wʌɾ ɪf aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɪt tə kip tɝnɪŋ? wi lɪv əɹ laɪvz baɪ ðə blʌɾ ʌv ʌðɝz! ən ðoʊz ʌðɝz bɪkʌm fɝɡɑɾən.

"What if I think it's all meaningless?" he demanded with the loud voice of a king. "What if I don't want it to keep turning? We live our lives by the blood of others! And those others become forgotten.

wʌt ɡʊɾ ɪz ɪɾ ɪf ɛvɹiθɪŋ wi noʊ wɪl feɪd? ɡɹeɪt didz əɹ ɡɹeɪt tʃɹædʒəɾiz, niðɝ minz ɛniθɪŋ! ðəl bɪkʌm lɛdʒənz, ðən ðoʊz lɛdʒənz wɪl bi fɝɡɑɾən, ðən ɪɾəl ɔl stɑɹɾ oʊvɝ əɡɛn!"

What good is it if everything we know will fade? Great deeds or great tragedies, neither means anything! They will become legends, then those legends will be forgotten, then it will all start over again!"

ði æksɛs ki bɪɡæn tə ɡloʊ ɪn ɪz hænz. ðə klaʊdz əbʌv sim tə ɡɹoʊ dɑɹkɝ.

The access key began to glow in his hands. The clouds above seemed to grow darker.

ɹændz æŋɡɝ biɾ ɪn ɹɪðəm wɪð ɪz hɑɹt, dɪmændɪŋ tə bi sɛt fɹi.

Rand's anger beat in rhythm with his heart, demanding to be set free.

"wʌɾ ɪf hiz ɹaɪt?" ɹænd bɛloʊd. "wʌɾ ɪf ɪts bɛɾɝ fəɹ ðɪs ɔl tə ɛnd? wʌɾ ɪf ðə laɪt wɑz ə laɪ ɔl əlɔŋ, ən ðɪs ɪz ɔl dʒʌst ə pʌnɪʃmənt? wi lɪv əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, ɡɹoʊɪŋ fibəl, daɪɪŋ, tʃɹæp fɝɛvɝ. wəɹ tə bi tɔɹtʃɝd fəɹ ɔl taɪm!"

"What if he is right?" Rand bellowed. "What if it's better for this all to end? What if the Light was a lie all along, and this is all just a punishment? We live again and again, growing feeble, dying, trapped forever. We are to be tortured for all time!"

paʊɝ flʌɾəd ɪndə ɹænd laɪk sɝdʒɪŋ weɪvz fɪlɪŋ ə nu oʊʃən. hi keɪm tə laɪf, ɡlɔɹiɪŋ ɪn seɪɾɪn, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ ðət ðə dɪspleɪ mʌs bi bɹɪljənli vɪzəbəl tə mɛn ɛvɹiwɛɹ u kəd tʃænəl.

Power flooded into Rand like surging waves filling a new ocean. He came to life, glorying in saidin, not caring that the display must be brilliantly visible to men everywhere who could channel.

hi fɛl hɪmsɛlf əlaɪt wɪð ðə paʊɝ, laɪk ə sʌn tə ðə wɝl bɪloʊ.

He felt himself alight with the Power, like a sun to the world below.

"nʌn ə ðɪs mæɾɝz!"

"NONE OF THIS MATTERS!"

hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪn mɔɹ ən mɔɹ paʊɝ, filɪŋ əz i hæɾ oʊnli twaɪs bɪfɔɹ. wʌns wən i hæd klɛnz seɪɾɪn. wʌns wən i hæd kɹieɪɾəd ðɪs maʊntən.

He closed his eyes, drawing in more and more power, feeling as he had only twice before. Once when he had cleansed saidin. Once when he had created this mountain.

ðən i dʒɹu ɪn mɔɹ.

Then he drew in more.

hi nu ðət mʌtʃ paʊɝ wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm. hi hæd stɑp kɛɹɪŋ. fjʊɹi ðət hæd bɪn bɪldɪŋ ɪn ɪm fəɹ tu jɪɹz faɪnəli bɔɪl fɹi, ənliʃt ət lɔŋ læst. hi spɹɛɾ ɪz ɑɹmz aʊt waɪd, æksɛs ki ɪn ɪz hænd. luz θɝɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪt tə kɪl hɪmsɛlf ən kɹieɪt dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. oʊnli hi hædnt ɡɔn fɑɹ ɪnʌf.

He knew that much power would destroy him. He had stopped caring. Fury that had been building in him for two years finally boiled free, unleashed at long last. He spread his arms out wide, access key in his hand. Lews Therin had been right to kill himself and create Dragonmount. Only he hadn't gone far enough.

ɹænd kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət deɪ. ðə smoʊk, ðə ɹʌmbəlɪŋ, ðə ʃɑɹp peɪnz ʌv ə hilɪŋ bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪm bæk tə lutʃɪɾəti əz i leɪ ɪn ə bɹoʊkən pæləs. bʌt ðoʊz peɪnz hæd peɪl kəmpɛɹd wɪð ði æɡəni ʌv ɹiləzeɪʃən. æɡəni fɹəm siɪŋ ðə bjuɾəfəl wɔlz skɑɹɾ ən bɹoʊkən. fɹəm siɪŋ ðə paɪlz ə fəmɪljɝ kɔɹpsəz, tɔs tə ðə flɔɹ laɪk dɪskɑɹɾɪd ɹæɡz.

Rand could remember that day. The smoke, the rumbling, the sharp pains of a Healing bringing him back to lucidity as he lay in a broken palace. But those pains had paled compared with the agony of realization. Agony from seeing the beautiful walls scarred and broken. From seeing the piles of familiar corpses, tossed to the floor like discarded rags.

fɹəm siɪŋ aɪlaɪɛnə ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns əweɪ, hɝ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn hɝ.

From seeing Ilyena a short distance away, her golden hair spread out on the ground around her.

hi kəd fil ðə pæləs ɝaʊn ɪm ʃeɪkɪŋ fɹəm ði ɝθs oʊn sɑbz. əɹ wɑz ðət dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, θɹɑbɪŋ fɹəm ði ɪmɛns paʊɝ i hæd dʒɹɔn ɪndə hɪmsɛlf?

He could feel the palace around him shaking from the earth's own sobs. Or was that Dragonmount, throbbing from the immense power he had drawn into himself?

hi kəd smɛl ði ɛɹ θɪk wɪð blʌɾ ən sʊɾ ən dɛθ ən peɪn. əɹ wɑz ðət dʒʌs ðə sɛn ʌv ə daɪɪŋ wɝld, spɹɛd bɪfɔɹ hɪm?

He could smell the air thick with blood and soot and death and pain. Or was that just the scent of a dying world, spread before him?

ðə wɪnz bɪɡæn tə wɪp ət hɪm, spɪnɪŋ, ɪnɔɹməs klaʊdz əbʌv twɪstɪŋ əpɑn ðɛmsɛlvz, laɪk eɪntʃən ləvaɪæθənz pæsɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹoʊfaʊn blæk dip.

The winds began to whip at him, spinning, enormous clouds above twisting upon themselves, like ancient leviathans passing in the profound black deep.

luz θɝɪn hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk. hi hæd daɪd, bʌt hæd lɛf ðə wɝld əlaɪv, wundəd, lɪmpɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. hid lɛt ðə wil ə taɪm kip tɝnɪŋ, ɹoʊteɪɾɪŋ, ɹɑɾɪŋ ən bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪm bæk ɝaʊn əɡɛn. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪskeɪp ɪt. nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ɛndɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

Lews Therin had made a mistake. He had died, but had left the world alive, wounded, limping forward. He'd let the Wheel of Time keep turning, rotating, rotting and bringing him back around again. He could not escape it. Not without ending everything.

"waɪ?" ɹænd wɪspɝd tə ðə twɪstɪŋ wɪnz ɝaʊn hɪm. ðə paʊɝ kʌmɪŋ tə hɪm θɹu ði æksɛs ki wɑz ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən hid hɛld wən klɛnzɪŋ seɪɾɪn. pɝhæps ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɛni mæn hæɾ ɛvɝ hɛld. ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnʌf tə ənɹævəl ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf ən bɹɪŋ faɪnəl pis.

"Why?" Rand whispered to the twisting winds around him. The Power coming to him through the access key was greater than he'd held when cleansing saidin. Perhaps greater than any man had ever held. Great enough to unravel the Pattern itself and bring final peace.

"waɪ də wɪv tə də ðɪs əɡɛn?" hi wɪspɝd. "aɪ hæv ɔlɹɛɾi feɪld. ʃiz dɛd baɪ maɪ hænd. waɪ mʌs jə meɪk mi laɪv ɪɾ əɡɛn?"

"Why do we have to do this again?" he whispered. "I have already failed. She is dead by my hand. Why must you make me live it again?"

laɪtnɪŋ kɹækt əbʌv, θʌndɝ bəfeɪɪŋ hɪm. ɹænd kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, pɝtʃt əbʌv ə dʒɹɑp ðət plʌməɾɪd θaʊzənz ə fit daʊnwɝd, ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə tɛmpəst ʌv aɪsi wɪnd. θɹu hɪz aɪlɪdz, hi kəd sɛns ðə bleɪzɪŋ laɪɾ ə ði æksɛs ki. ðə paʊɝ i hɛld ɪnsaɪd dwɔɹf ðət laɪt. hi wɑz ðə sʌn. hi wɑz faɪɝ. hi wɑz laɪf ən dɛθ.

Lightning cracked above, thunder buffeting him. Rand closed his eyes, perched above a drop that plummeted thousands of feet downward, in the middle of a tempest of icy wind. Through his eyelids, he could sense the blazing light of the access key. The Power he held inside dwarfed that light. He was the sun. He was fire. He was life and death.

waɪ? waɪ mʌs ðeɪ də ðɪs oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ? ðə wɝl kəd ɡɪv ɪm noʊ ænsɝz.

Why? Why must they do this over and over? The world could give him no answers.

ɹænd ɹeɪzd ɪz ɑɹmz haɪ, ə kɑnduɪɾ ə paʊɝ ən ɛnɝdʒi. ən ɪnkɑɹneɪʃən ə dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. hi wəɾ ɛn ɪt. ɛn ɪɾ ɔl ən lɛt mɛn ɹɛst, faɪnəli, fɹəm ðɛɹ sʌfɝɪŋ.

Rand raised his arms high, a conduit of power and energy. An incarnation of death and destruction. He would end it. End it all and let men rest, finally, from their suffering.

stɑp əm fɹəm hævɪŋ tə lɪv oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ əɡɛn. waɪ? waɪ hæd ðə kɹieɪɾɝ dʌn ðɪs tə ðɛm?

Stop them from having to live over and over again. Why? Why had the Creator done this to them?

waɪ?

Why?

waɪ də wi laɪv əɡɛn? luz θɝɪn æskt, sʌɾənli. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz kɹɪsp ən dɪstɪŋkt.

Why do we live again? Lews Therin asked, suddenly. His voice was crisp and distinct.

jɛs, ɹænd sɛd, pliɾɪŋ. tɛl mi. waɪ?

Yes, Rand said, pleading. Tell me. Why?

meɪbi . . . luz θɝɪn sɛd, ʃɑkɪŋli lusəd, nɑɾ ə hɪn ə mædnəs tə hɪm. hi spoʊk sɔfli, ɹɛvɝənli. waɪ? kəɾ ɪt bi . . . meɪbi ɪts soʊ ðət wi kən əv ə sɛkən tʃæns.

Maybe . . . Lews Therin said, shockingly lucid, not a hint of madness to him. He spoke softly, reverently. Why? Could it be . . . Maybe it's so that we can have a second chance.

ɹænd fɹoʊz. ðə wɪnz blu əɡɛns hɪm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt bi muv baɪ ðɛm. ðə paʊɝ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ɪnsaɪd hɪm, laɪk ðə hɛdzmənz æks, hɛl kwɪvɝɪŋ əbʌv ðə kɹɪmənəlz nɛk. jə meɪ nɑɾ əv ə tʃɔɪs əbaʊt wɪtʃ duɾiz ɑɹ ɡɪvən ju, tæmz vɔɪs, dʒʌst ə mɛmɹi, sɛɾ ɪn ɪz maɪnd. bʌt jə kən tʃuz waɪ jə fʊlfɪl ðɛm.

Rand froze. The winds blew against him, but he could not be moved by them. The Power hesitated inside him, like the headsman's axe, held quivering above the criminal's neck. You may not have a choice about which duties are given you, Tam's voice, just a memory, said in his mind. But you can choose why you fulfill them.

waɪ, ɹænd? waɪ dʒju ɡoʊ tə bæɾəl? wʌɾ ɪz ðə pɔɪnt?

Why, Rand? Why do you go to battle? What is the point?

waɪ?

Why?

ɔl wɑz stɪl. ivən wɪð ðə tɛmpəst, ðə wɪnz, ðə kɹæʃɪz ə θʌndɝ. ɔl wɑz stɪl.

All was still. Even with the tempest, the winds, the crashes of thunder. All was still.

waɪ? ɹænd θɔt wɪð wʌndɝ. kəz itʃ taɪm wi laɪv, wi ɡɛt tə lʌv əɡɛn.

Why? Rand thought with wonder. Because each time we live, we get to love again.

ðət wɑz ði ænsɝ. ɪɾ ɔl swɛpt oʊvɝ hɪm, laɪvz lɪvd, mɪsteɪks meɪd, lʌv tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

That was the answer. It all swept over him, lives lived, mistakes made, love changing everything.

hi sɔ ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld ɪn ɪz maɪnz aɪ, lɪt baɪ ðə ɡloʊ ɪn ɪz hænd. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd laɪvz, hʌnʒɹədz ə ðɛm, θaʊzənz ə ðɛm, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ tə ɪnfɪnəɾi. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd lʌv, ən pis, ən dʒɔɪ, ən hoʊp.

He saw the entire world in his mind's eye, lit by the glow in his hand. He remembered lives, hundreds of them, thousands of them, stretching to infinity. He remembered love, and peace, and joy, and hope.

wɪðɪn ðət moʊmənt, sʌɾənli sʌmθɪŋ əmeɪzɪŋ əkɝd tə hɪm. ɪf aɪ laɪv əɡɛn, ðən ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl!

Within that moment, suddenly something amazing occurred to him. If I live again, then she might as well!

ðæts waɪ hi fɔt. ðæts waɪ hi lɪvd əɡɛn, ən ðət wɑz ði ænsɝ tə tæmz kwɛstʃən. aɪ faɪt kəz læs taɪm, aɪ feɪld. aɪ faɪt kəz aɪ wɑnə fɪks wʌɾ aɪ dɪd ɹɔŋ.

That's why he fought. That's why he lived again, and that was the answer to Tam's question. I fight because last time, I failed. I fight because I want to fix what I did wrong.

aɪ wɑnə də ɪt ɹaɪt ðɪs taɪm.

I want to do it right this time.

ðə paʊɝ wɪðɪn ɪm ɹitʃt ə kɹɪʃɛndoʊ, ən i tɝn ɪɾ əpɑn ɪtsɛlf, dʒɹoʊv ɪt θɹu ði æksɛs ki. ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz kənɛktəd tə ə mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪɾɝ fɔɹs, ə mæsɪv sɑŋɡɹil tə ðə saʊθ, bɪl tə stɑp ðə dɑɹk wʌn. tu paʊɝfəl, səm hæd sɛd. tu paʊɝfəl ɛvɝ tə juz. tu fɹaɪɾənɪŋ.

The Power within him reached a crescendo, and he turned it upon itself, drove it through the access key. The ter'angreal was connected to a much greater force, a massive sa'angreal to the south, built to stop the Dark One. Too powerful, some had said. Too powerful ever to use. Too frightening.

ɹænd juzd ɪts oʊn paʊɝ əpɑn ɪt, kɹʌʃɪŋ ðə dɪstənt ɡloʊb, ʃæɾɝɪŋ ɪɾ əz ɪf ɪn ðə ɡɹɪp ʌv ə dʒaɪəns hænz.

Rand used its own power upon it, crushing the distant globe, shattering it as if in the grip of a giant's hands.

ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl ɪksploʊɾəd.

The Choedan Kal exploded.

ðə paʊɝ wɪŋkt aʊt.

The Power winked out.

ðə tɛmpəst ɛndəd.

The tempest ended.

ən ɹænd oʊpən ɪz aɪz fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn ə vɛɹi lɔŋ waɪl. hi nu - sʌmhaʊ - ðəɾ i wəd nɛvɝ əɡɛn hɪɹ luz θɝɪnz vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd. fəɹ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt tu mɛn, ən nɛvɝ hæd bɪn.

And Rand opened his eyes for the first time in a very long while. He knew - somehow - that he would never again hear Lews Therin's voice in his head. For they were not two men, and never had been.

hi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə wɝl bɪniθ hɪm. ðə klaʊdz əbʌv hæd faɪnəli bɹoʊkən, ɪf oʊnli dʒʌst əbʌv hɪm.

He regarded the world beneath him. The clouds above had finally broken, if only just above him.

ðə ɡlum dɪspɝst, əlaʊɪŋ ɪm tə si ðə sʌn hæŋɪŋ dʒʌst əbʌv.

The gloom dispersed, allowing him to see the sun hanging just above.

ɹænd lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪt. ðən i smaɪld. faɪnəli, hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə dip-θɹoʊɾɪd læf, tʃɹu ən pjʊɹ.

Rand looked up at it. Then he smiled. Finally, he let out a deep-throated laugh, true and pure.

ɪt hæd bɪn fɑɹ tu lɔŋ.

It had been far too long.


ɛpəlɔɡ beɪðd ɪn laɪt



EPILOGUE Bathed in Light

ɛɡwin wɝk baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə tu bɹɑnz læmps. ðeɪ wɝ ʃeɪp laɪk wɪmən hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ hænz ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ə bɝst ə fleɪm əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn itʃ sɛɾ ə pɑmz. ðə kɑm jɛloʊ laɪt ɹəflɛktəɾ ɑn ðə kɝvz ə ðɛɹ hænz, ɑɹmz ən feɪsəz. wɝ ðeɪ sɪmbəlz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn? əɹ wɝ ðeɪ ɪnstɛd dɪpɪkʃənz ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, wivɪŋ faɪɝ? pɝhæps ðeɪ wɝ sɪmpli ɹɛlɪks ʌv ə pɹiviəs æmɪɝlɪnz teɪst.

Egwene worked by the light of two bronze lamps. They were shaped like women holding their hands into the air, a burst of flame appearing in each set of palms. The calm yellow light reflected on the curves of their hands, arms and faces. Were they symbols of the White Tower and the Flame of Tar Valon? Or were they instead depictions of an Aes Sedai, weaving Fire? Perhaps they were simply relics of a previous Amyrlin's taste.

ðeɪ sæɾ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɝ dɛsk. ə pɹɑpɝ dɛsk, faɪnəli, wɪð ə pɹɑpɝ tʃɛɹ tə sɪɾ əpɑn. ʃi wɑz ɪnsaɪd ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi, pɝdʒd ʌv ɛni ən ɔl ɹɛfɝənsɪz tə ɪleɪɾə. ðət lɛft ɪt bɛɹ, ðə wɔlz ɛmpti, ðə wʊd pænəlɪŋ ʌnədɔɹn baɪ pɪktʃɝ əɹ tæpəstʃɹi, ði ɛn teɪbəlz ɛmpti ʌv wɝks ʌv ɑɹt.

They sat on either side of her desk. A proper desk, finally, with a proper chair to sit upon. She was inside the Amyrlin's study, purged of any and all references to Elaida. That left it bare, the walls empty, the wood paneling unadorned by picture or tapestry, the end tables empty of works of art.

ivən ðə bʊkʃɛlvz hæd bɪn ɛmptid, lɛst sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ɪleɪɾəz əfɛn ɛɡwin.

Even the bookshelves had been emptied, lest something of Elaida's offend Egwene.

ðə moʊmən ɛɡwin hæd sin wʌt ði ʌðɝz hæd dʌn, ʃi hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɔl ʌv ɪleɪɾəz ɪfɛks ɡæðɝɾ ən pleɪst ʌndɝ sɪkjʊɹ lɑk, ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ wɪmən ɛɡwin tʃɹʌstɪd. hɪɾən əmʌŋ ðoʊz ɪfɛks wəd bi kluz tə ɪleɪɾəz plænz. ðeɪ maɪt sɪmpli bi hɪɾən noʊts slɪp bɪtwin ðə peɪdʒəz ə bʊks, lɛft fəɹ fɝðɝ ɹivju. əɹ ðeɪ maɪt bi əz əbskjʊɹ əz kənɛkʃənz bɪtwin ðə taɪps ə bʊks ʃid bɪn ɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ ði aɪɾəmz ʃid hæɾ ɪn ðə dɛsk dʒɹɔɹz. bʌt ðeɪ dɪdn əv ɪleɪɾə hɝsɛlf tə kwɛstʃən, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ wʌt skimz ə hɝz wəd ɹɪtɝn tə baɪt ðə waɪt taʊɝ əɾ ə leɪɾɝ deɪt. ɛɡwin ɪntɛndəd tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðoʊz ɑbʒɛkts, ðən ɪntɝvju itʃ ən ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd bɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ ən dətɝmən wʌt kluz ðeɪ hɪd.

The moment Egwene had seen what the others had done, she had ordered all of Elaida's effects gathered and placed under secure lock, guarded by women Egwene trusted. Hidden among those effects would be clues to Elaida's plans. They might simply be hidden notes slipped between the pages of books, left for further review. Or they might be as obscure as connections between the types of books she'd been reading or the items she'd had in the desk drawers. But they didn't have Elaida herself to question, and there was no telling what schemes of hers would return to bite the White Tower at a later date. Egwene intended to look over those objects, then interview each and every Aes Sedai who had been in the Tower and determine what clues they hid.

fəɹ naʊ, ʃi hæɾ əɹ hænz fʊl. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, tɝnɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə peɪdʒəz ə sɪlviænəz ɹipɔɹt.

For now, she had her hands full. She shook her head, turning over the pages of Silviana's report.

ðə wʊmən wɑz pɹuvɪŋ tə bi ən ɪfɛktɪv kipɝ ɪndid, fɑɹ mɔɹ skɪl ðən ʃɛɹiəm hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn. ðə lɔɪəlɪst wɪmən ɹɪspɛktɪd sɪlviænə, ən ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ sim tə hæv æksɛptɪd - ət list ɪn pɑɹt - ɛɡwinz ɔfɝ ə pis ɪn tʃuzɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛɹ oʊn əz əɹ kipɝ.

The woman was proving to be an effective Keeper indeed, far more skilled than Sheriam had ever been. The loyalist women respected Silviana, and the Red Ajah seemed to have accepted - at least in part - Egwene's offer of peace in choosing one of their own as her Keeper.

ʌv kɔɹs, ɛɡwin ɔlsoʊ hæd tu stɪf lɛɾɝz ə dɪsəpɹuvəl - wʌn fɹəm ɹoʊmændə ən wʌn fɹəm ləleɪn - ɑn ðə bɑɾəm ə hɝ stæk. ðə tu wɪmən hæd wɪθdʒɹɔn ðɛɹ ɛfjusɪv səpɔɹɾ ɔlmoʊst əz kwɪkli əz ðeɪd ɡɪvən ɪt. ɹaɪt naʊ, ðeɪ wɝ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌt tə də wɪð ðə deɪmeɪn ɛɡwin hæd kæptʃɝd dʊɹɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɹeɪd, ən niðɝ wʌn laɪkt ɛɡwinz plæn tə tʃɹeɪn əm əz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn wəd tʃɹʌbəl əɹ fəɹ jɪɹz jɛt, ɪɾ əpɪɹd.

Of course, Egwene also had two stiff letters of disapproval - one from Romanda and one from Lelaine - on the bottom of her stack. The two women had withdrawn their effusive support almost as quickly as they'd given it. Right now, they were arguing over what to do with the damane Egwene had captured during the White Tower raid, and neither one liked Egwene's plan to train them as Aes Sedai. Romanda and Lelaine would trouble her for years yet, it appeared.

ʃi sɛt ðə ɹipɔɹɾ əsaɪd. ɪt wɑz leɪɾ æftɝnun, ən laɪt pik θɹu ðə slɪts ə ðə luvɝd ʃʌɾɝz tə hɝ bælkəni. ʃi dɪdn oʊpən ðɛm, pɹɪfɝɪŋ ðə kwaɪət dɪmnəs. ðə sɑlətud fɛl naɪs.

She set the report aside. It was late afternoon, and light peeked through the slits of the louvered shutters to her balcony. She didn't open them, preferring the quiet dimness. The solitude felt nice.

fəɹ naʊ, ʃi dɪdn maɪn ðə ɹumz spɑɹs dɛkɝeɪʃənz. tʃɹu, ɪt ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl tu mʌtʃ ə ðə stʌɾi ʌv ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, bʌt noʊ nʌmbɝ ʌv wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz wəd bænɪʃ əɹ mɛmɹi ʌv ðoʊz deɪz, nɑt wən sɪlviænə hɝsɛlf wɑz ɛɡwinz kipɝ. ðət wɑz faɪn. waɪ wəɾ ɛɡwin wɑnə bænɪʃ ðoʊz deɪz? ðeɪ kənteɪn səm ə hɝ moʊst sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ vɪktɝiz.

For now, she didn't mind the room's sparse decorations. True, it reminded her just a little too much of the study of the Mistress of Novices, but no number of wall hangings would banish her memory of those days, not when Silviana herself was Egwene's Keeper. That was fine. Why would Egwene want to banish those days? They contained some of her most satisfying victories.

ðoʊ ʃi sɝɾənli dɪdn maɪn biɪŋ eɪbəl tə sɪt wɪθaʊt kɹɪŋɪŋ.

Though she certainly didn't mind being able to sit without cringing.

ʃi smaɪl feɪnli, skænɪŋ ðə nɛkst ə sɪlviænəz ɹɪpɔɹts. ðən ʃi fɹaʊnd. moʊst ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪn ðə taʊɝ hæɾ ɪskeɪpt. ðɪs ɹipɔɹt, ɹɪɾən ɪn sɪlviænəz kɛɹfəl, floʊɪŋ skɹɪpt, toʊl ðət ðeɪ hæd mænədʒ tə siz səm ə ðə blæks ɪn ði aʊɝz fɑloʊɪŋ ɛɡwinz ɹeɪzɪŋ, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə wikəst ə ðə lɑt. ðə mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv əm - səm sɪksti blæk sɪstɝz - hæɾ ɪskeɪpt. ɪnkluɾɪŋ wʌn sɪɾɝ, əz ɛɡwin hæd noʊɾəst bɪfɔɹ, huz neɪm hæd nɑt bɪn ɑn vɛɹɪnz lɪst. ɛvænɛlaɪnz dɪsəpɪɹəns ɪndəkeɪɾəd stʃɹɔŋli ðət ʃi wɑz blæk.

She smiled faintly, scanning the next of Silviana's reports. Then she frowned. Most of the Black Ajah in the Tower had escaped. This report, written in Silviana's careful, flowing script, told that they had managed to seize some of the Blacks in the hours following Egwene's raising, but only the weakest of the lot. The majority of them - some sixty Black sisters - had escaped. Including one Sitter, as Egwene had noticed before, whose name had not been on Verin's list. Evanellein's disappearance indicated strongly that she was Black.

ɛɡwin pɪkt ʌp ənʌðɝ ɹipɔɹt, fɹaʊnɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. ɪt wɑz ə lɪst ʌv ɔl ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ɪkstɛnsɪv lɪst sɛvɹəl peɪdʒəz lɔŋ, bɹoʊkən daʊn baɪ ədʒɑ. mɛni neɪmz hæɾ ə noʊteɪʃən bɪsaɪd ðɛm. blæk, ɪskeɪpt. blæk, kæptʃɝd. teɪkən baɪ ðə sintʃæn.

Egwene picked up another report, frowning to herself. It was a list of all the women in the White Tower, an extensive list several pages long, broken down by Ajah. Many names had a notation beside them. Black, escaped. Black, captured. Taken by the Seanchan.

ðət læst ɡɹup wɑz ɡɔlɪŋ. sɹɪn - æktɪŋ wɪð fɔɹsaɪt - hæd teɪkən ə sɛnsəs fɑloʊɪŋ ði ətæk tə dətɝmən ɪɡzækli hu hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd. nɪɹli fɔɹɾi ɪnɪʃiəts - oʊvɝ tu dʌzən ə ðɛm fʊl ɛɛs sədaɪ - snætʃt ɪn ðə naɪɾ ən kæɹiɾ ɔf. ɪt wɑz laɪk ə stɔɹi toʊl tə tʃɪlʒɹən ət bɛdtaɪm, wɔɹnɪŋ ə feɪdz əɹ hæfmən u stoʊl wɪkəd tʃɪlʒɹən. ðoʊz wɪmən wəd bi biɾən, kənfaɪn ən tɝn ɪndə nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tulz.

That last group was galling. Saerin - acting with foresight - had taken a census following the attack to determine exactly who had been captured. Nearly forty initiates - over two dozen of them full Aes Sedai - snatched in the night and carried off. It was like a story told to children at bedtime, warning of Fades or Halfmen who stole wicked children. Those women would be beaten, confined and turned into nothing more than tools.

ɛɡwin hæd tə stil hɝsɛlf fɹəm ɹitʃɪŋ ʌp tə fil əɹ nɛk, wɛɹ ðə kɑlɝ hæd hɛl hɝ. ʃi wɑzn foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ðət ɹaɪt naʊ, bɝn ɪɾ ɔl!

Egwene had to steel herself from reaching up to feel her neck, where the collar had held her. She wasn't focusing on that right now, burn it all!

itʃ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ mɛmbɝz ɑn vɛɹɪnz lɪs hæd bɪn sin hɛlθi ən əlaɪv fɑloʊɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ətæk. bʌt moʊs hæɾ ɪskeɪp bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin ɝaɪvd ət ðə taʊɝ tə teɪk əɹ sit. vɛlinə wɑz ɡɔn. soʊ wɝ tʃaɪ ən bɝlən. ən ɑlviɛɝɪn; ðə blæk hʌntɝz hædn mænədʒ tə ɡɛt tə hɝ ɪn taɪm.

Each of the Black Ajah members on Verin's list had been seen healthy and alive following the Seanchan attack. But most had escaped before Egwene arrived at the Tower to take her seat. Velina was gone. So were Chai and Birlen. And Alviarin; the Black hunters hadn't managed to get to her in time.

wʌt hæd tɪpt əm ɔf? ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ɪt hæd pɹɑbli sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɛɡwin sizɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪn ðə ɹɛbəl kæmp. ʃi hæd wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ oʊvɝpleɪɪŋ əɹ hænd. bʌt wʌɾ ɛls ʃəd ʃi hæv dʌn? hɝ oʊnli hoʊp hæd bɪn tə siz ɛvɹi blæk ɪn ðə kæmp ən hoʊp ðət wɝd dɪdn spɹɛd tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

What had tipped them off? Unfortunately, it had probably something to do with Egwene seizing the Black Ajah in the rebel camp. She had worried about overplaying her hand. But what else should she have done? Her only hope had been to seize every Black in the camp and hope that word didn't spread to the White Tower.

bʌɾ ɪt hæd. ʃid kæptʃɝd ðə wʌnz u ɹɪmeɪnd, ən hæɾ əm ɛksəkjuɾəd. ðən ʃid ɹɪswɔɹn ɛvɹi sɪstɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd. ðeɪ hædn laɪkt ɪt, ʌv kɔɹs. bʌt ðə nɑlədʒ ðəɾ ɔl ə ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə ɹɛbəl kæmp hæd dʌn ɪt hæd sweɪd ðɛm. ɪf ɪt hædnt, ðə nuz ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ði ɛksəkjuʃən ə hɝ oʊn kipɝ pɹɑbli dɪd. ɪt hæd sɝɾənli bɪn ə ɹɪlif wən sɪlviænə hæɾ ɔfɝd tə swɛɹ fɝst, ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪntaɪɝ hɔl, tə pɹuv hɝsɛlf. ɛɡwin hæd fɑloʊd baɪ ɹɛswɛɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ðən toʊl ðə hɔl tʃɹuθfəli ðət ʃi hæd wɑtʃt itʃ ən ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə kæmp pɹuv ðət ʃi wɑzn ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. ðeɪd kæptʃɝd θɹi mɔɹ blæk sɪstɝz u hædn bɪn ɑn vɛɹɪnz lɪst. oʊnli θɹi. wʌɾ ækjɝəsi! vɛɹɪn hæd pɹuvən hɝsɛlf wʌns əɡɛn.

But it had. She'd captured the ones who remained, and had them executed. Then she'd resworn every sister in the Tower on the Oath Rod. They hadn't liked it, of course. But the knowledge that all of the women in the rebel camp had done it had swayed them. If it hadn't, the news that Egwene had ordered the execution of her own Keeper probably did. It had certainly been a relief when Silviana had offered to swear first, in front of the entire Hall, to prove herself. Egwene had followed by reswearing herself, then told the Hall truthfully that she had watched each and every woman in the camp prove that she wasn't a Darkfriend. They'd captured three more Black sisters who hadn't been on Verin's list. Only three. What accuracy! Verin had proven herself once again.

ɛɡwin sɛɾ əsaɪd ðə ɹipɔɹt. nɑlədʒ ə ðoʊz u hæɾ ɪskeɪp stɪl tʃuɾ ət hɝ. ʃi hæd noʊn ðə neɪmz ə sɪksti dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən ðeɪ hæɾ ɪskeɪpt əɹ ɡɹæsp. ðət nʌmbɝ ɹitʃt tə eɪɾi ɪf ʃi ɪnkluɾəd ðoʊz u hæɾ ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðə ɹɛbəl kæmp.

Egwene set aside the report. Knowledge of those who had escaped still chewed at her. She had known the names of sixty Darkfriends, and they had escaped her grasp. That number reached to eighty if she included those who had escaped from the rebel camp.

əl faɪn ju, ɑlviɛɝɪn, ɛɡwin θɔt, tæpɪŋ ðə ʃit wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝ. əl faɪn jə ɔl.

I will find you, Alviarin, Egwene thought, tapping the sheet with her finger. I will find you all.

jə wɝ ə ɹɑt wɪðɪn ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. ðə wɝs kaɪndə ɹɑt. əl nɑt lɛt jə spɹɛɾ ɪt.

You were a rot within the Tower itself. The worst kind of rot. I will not let you spread it.

ʃi sɛt ðə ʃiɾ əsaɪɾ ən pɪkt ʌp ənʌðɝ. ðɪs wʌn bɔɹ oʊnli ə fju neɪmz. ə lɪst ʌv ɔl ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ u hæd nɑt bɪn ɑn vɛɹɪnz lɪst ən u hæɾ iðɝ bɪn teɪkən baɪ ðə sintʃæn, əɹ hæd dɪsəpɪɹd fɑloʊɪŋ ði ətæk.

She set the sheet aside and picked up another. This one bore only a few names. A list of all the women in the Tower who had not been on Verin's list and who had either been taken by the Seanchan, or had disappeared following the attack.

vɛɹɪn hæd bɪliv ðət wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, mɛsænə, wɑz haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊɝ. ʃɛɹiəmz kənfɛʃən kɝɑbɝeɪɾɪd ðɪs. ɛɡwinz tæsk ə ɹɛswɛɹɪŋ ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ðə ɹɑd hæd ɹɪvil noʊ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ. hoʊpfəli, ðə ɹɛswɛɹɪŋ ɪtsɛlf wəɾ iz ðə tɛnʃən bɪtwin ði ədʒəz. ðeɪ kəd stɑp wɝiɪŋ ɪf ðəɹ wɝ blæks ɪn ðɛɹ mɪdst. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt kəd vɛɹi wɛl wikən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ baɪ ɡɪvɪŋ pɹuf ðət ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæɾ ɪndiɾ ɪɡzɪstəɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs.

Verin had believed that one of the Forsaken, Mesaana, was hiding in the Tower. Sheriam's confession corroborated this. Egwene's task of reswearing every Aes Sedai on the Rod had revealed no Darkfriends of great power. Hopefully, the reswearing itself would ease the tension between the Ajahs. They could stop worrying if there were Blacks in their midst. Of course, it could very well weaken the Aes Sedai by giving proof that the Black Ajah had indeed existed in the first place.

iðɝ weɪ, ɛɡwin hæɾ ə pɹɑbləm. ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə ʃit bɪfɔɹ hɝ. itʃ wʊmən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd pɹuvən ðət ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. itʃ wʊmən ɑn vɛɹɪnz lɪst wɑz əkaʊntəd fɔɹ. ʃid bɪn ɛksəkjuɾəd, ʃid bɪn kæptʃɝd, ʃid flɛd ðə waɪt taʊɝ ðə deɪ ʌv ɛɡwinz əsɛnʃən, ʃid bɪn teɪkən baɪ ðə sintʃæn əɹ ʃi wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ət ðə moʊmənt - ən hæd bɪn fəɹ səm taɪm. ðə sɪstɝz hæɾ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə wɑtʃ fəɹ ðoʊz.

Either way, Egwene had a problem. She looked over the sheet before her. Each woman in the White Tower had proven that she was not a Darkfriend. Each woman on Verin's list was accounted for. She'd been executed, she'd been captured, she'd fled the White Tower the day of Egwene's ascension, she'd been taken by the Seanchan or she was out of the Tower at the moment - and had been for some time. The sisters had instructions to watch for those.

pɝhæps ðeɪd bɪn lʌki, ən ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪmən u hæd bɪn teɪkən baɪ ðə sintʃæn. bʌɾ ɛɡwin dɪdn bɪliv ɪn ðət kaɪndə lʌk. wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wəd nɑt bi kæptʃɝd soʊ izəli. ʃid pɹɑbli noʊn əbaʊt ði ətæk ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs.

Perhaps they'd been lucky, and the Forsaken was one of those women who had been taken by the Seanchan. But Egwene didn't believe in that kind of luck. One of the Forsaken would not be captured so easily. She'd probably known about the attack in the first place.

ðət lɛf ðə θɹi neɪmz ɑn ðə lɪst ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛɡwin. nɑleɪsə mɝən, ə bɹaʊn; tɝəminə, ə ɡɹin; ən dʒəmɪlɪlə nɔɹsɪʃ, ə ɹɛd. ɔl wɝ vɛɹi wik ɪn ðə paʊɝ. ən ðə wɪmən ɑn ðɪs lɪs hæɾ ɔl bɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ fəɹ jɪɹz. ɪt simd ɪmplɔzəbəl ðət mɛsænə hæd bɪn ɪmpɝsəneɪɾɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛm ən duɪŋ ɪt soʊ wɛl ðəɾ əɹ sʌbtɝfjudʒ hædn bɪn noʊɾəst.

That left the three names on the list in front of Egwene. Nalasia Merhan, a Brown; Teramina, a Green; and Jamilila Norsish, a Red. All were very weak in the Power. And the women on this list had all been in the Tower for years. It seemed implausible that Mesaana had been impersonating one of them and doing it so well that her subterfuge hadn't been noticed.

ɛɡwin hæɾ ə filɪŋ. ə pɹimənɪʃən, pɝhæps. ət ðə vɛɹi list, ə fɪɹ. ðiz θɹi neɪmz wɝ ði oʊnli wʌnz u cʊɾə bɪn ðə fɔɹseɪkən. bʌt nʌn ə ðɛm fɪt, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl. ðət ɡeɪv əɹ ə tʃɪl.

Egwene had a feeling. A premonition, perhaps. At the very least, a fear. These three names were the only ones who could have been the Forsaken. But none of them fit, not at all. That gave her a chill.

wɑz mɛsænə stɪl haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊɝ?

Was Mesaana still hiding in the Tower?

ɪf soʊ, ʃi sʌmhaʊ nu haʊ tə dɪfit ði oʊθ ɹɑd.

If so, she somehow knew how to defeat the Oath Rod.

ə sɑf nɑk keɪm əɾ əɹ dɔɹ. ɪt kɹækt ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ. "mʌðɝ?" sɪlviænə æskt.

A soft knock came at her door. It cracked a moment later. "Mother?" Silviana asked.

ɛɡwin lʊkt ʌp, ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ aɪbɹaʊz.

Egwene looked up, raising her eyebrows.

"aɪ θɔt jə maɪt wɑnə si ðɪs," sɪlviænə sɛd, ɛntɝɪŋ, hɝ hɛɹ bæk ɪn ɪts taɪɾi blæk bʌn, ðə ɹɛd kipɝz stoʊl ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz.

"I thought you might want to see this," Silviana said, entering, her hair back in its tidy black bun, the red Keeper's stole around her shoulders.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"What is it?"

"ju ʃəd kʌm ən si."

"You should come and see."

kjʊɹiəs, ɛɡwin ɹoʊz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛnʃən tə sɪlviænəz vɔɪs, soʊ ɪt kʊdn bi ɛniθɪŋ tu daɪɹ. ðə tu ʌv əm lɛf ðə stʌɾi bɪhaɪnd, wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ tə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ɪt, ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. sɪlviænə dʒɛstʃɝd fəɹ əɹ tə ɛntɝ.

Curious, Egwene rose. There was no tension to Silviana's voice, so it couldn't be anything too dire. The two of them left the study behind, walking around the outside of the building to the Hall of the Tower. When they reached it, Egwene raised an eyebrow. Silviana gestured for her to enter.
