ðə hɔl wɑzn ɪn sɛʃən, ən ðə tʃɛɹz sæɾ ɛmpti. ə skæɾɝɪŋ ə meɪsənz tulz leɪ ɑn waɪt ʃits ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ən ə ɡɹup ʌv wɝkɝz ɪn θɪk bɹaʊn oʊvɝɔlz ən waɪt ʃɝts - slivz ɹoʊld ʌp - wɝ kəlɛktəɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡæp ɪn ðə wɔl ðət ðə sintʃæn hæd lɛft. ɛɡwin hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ə ɹoʊz wɪndoʊ fɪɾəd ɪndə ði oʊpənɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ə hævɪŋ ɪt sild ʌp kəmplitli, ə ɹimɛmbɹəns fəɹ ðə taɪm ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd bɪn ətækt. ə wɔɹnɪŋ tə pɹɪvɛn ɪts hæpənɪŋ əɡɛn. bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪndoʊ kəd bi ɪnstɔld, haʊɛvɝ, stoʊnmeɪsɑnz wɝ bɪzi ʃɔɹɪŋ ʌp ðə saɪdz ən kɹieɪɾɪŋ ðə fɪɾɪŋ.

The Hall wasn't in session, and the chairs sat empty. A scattering of mason's tools lay on white sheets in the corner, and a group of workers in thick brown overalls and white shirts - sleeves rolled up - were collected in front of the gap in the wall that the Seanchan had left. Egwene had ordered a rose window fitted into the opening instead of having it sealed up completely, a remembrance for the time the White Tower had been attacked. A warning to prevent its happening again. Before the window could be installed, however, stonemasons were busy shoring up the sides and creating the fitting.

ɛɡwin ən sɪlviænə ɡlaɪɾɪd ɪndə ðə ɹum, wɔkɪŋ daʊn ðə ʃɔɹt ɹæmp tə ðə flɔɹ, wɪtʃ hæɾ əɡɛn bɪn pɹɑpɝli peɪntəd wɪð ðə kʌlɝz ʌv ɔl sɛvən ədʒəz. ðə stoʊnmeɪsɑnz sɔ ðɛm, ðən bækt əweɪ ɹɪspɛkfəli, wʌn mæn pʊlɪŋ ɔf ɪz kæp ən klʌtʃɪŋ ɪt tə hɪz tʃɛst. ɹitʃɪŋ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹum, dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ði oʊpənɪŋ, ɛɡwin faɪnəli sɔ wʌt sɪlviænə hæd bɹɔɾ əɹ tə si.

Egwene and Silviana glided into the room, walking down the short ramp to the floor, which had again been properly painted with the colors of all seven Ajahs. The stonemasons saw them, then backed away respectfully, one man pulling off his cap and clutching it to his chest. Reaching the edge of the room, just before the opening, Egwene finally saw what Silviana had brought her to see.

æftɝ ɔl ðɪs taɪm, ðə klaʊdz hæd faɪnəli bɹoʊkən. ðeɪ hæd pʊl bæk ɪn ə ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. ðə sʌn ʃoʊn daʊn, ɹeɪɾiənt, laɪɾɪŋ ðə dɪstənt, snoʊkæp kɹæɡ. ðə bɹoʊkən mɔ ən ʌpɝmoʊs pik ə ðə blæstəd maʊntənsaɪd wɝ beɪðd ɪn laɪt. ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɛɡwin kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ siɪŋ dɝɛk sʌnlaɪɾ ɪn wiks. pɝhæps lɔŋɡɝ.

After all this time, the clouds had finally broken. They had pulled back in a ring around Dragonmount. The sun shone down, radiant, lighting the distant, snowcapped crag. The broken maw and uppermost peak of the blasted mountainside were bathed in light. It was the first time Egwene could remember seeing direct sunlight in weeks. Perhaps longer.

"sʌm nɑvəsɪz noʊɾəst ɪt fɝst, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd hɝ. "ænd nuz spɹɛd kwɪkli. hu wʊɾə θɔt ðəɾ ə lɪɾəl ɹɪŋ ə sʌnlaɪt wəd kɑz sətʃ ə stɝ? ɪts sətʃ ə sɪmpəl θɪŋ, ɹɪli. nʌθɪŋ wi hævən sin bɪfɔɹ. bʌt. . . ."

"Some novices noticed it first, Mother," Silviana said, stepping up beside her. "And news spread quickly. Who would have thought that a little ring of sunlight would cause such a stir? It's such a simple thing, really. Nothing we haven't seen before. But. . . ."

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ bjuɾəfəl əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðə laɪt stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn ɪn ə kɑləm, stʃɹɔŋ ən pjʊɹ.

There was something beautiful about it. The light streaming down in a column, strong and pure.

dɪstənt, jɛt stʃɹaɪkɪŋ. ɪt wɑz laɪk sʌmθɪŋ fɝɡɑɾən, bʌt sʌmhaʊ stɪl fəmɪljɝ, ʃaɪnɪŋ fɔɹθ fɹəm ə dɪstən mɛmɹi tə bɹɪŋ wɔɹmθ əɡɛn.

Distant, yet striking. It was like something forgotten, but somehow still familiar, shining forth from a distant memory to bring warmth again.

"wʌt dʌz ɪt min?" sɪlviænə æskt.

"What does it mean?" Silviana asked.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ wɛlkəm ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɪt." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ðæɾ oʊpənɪŋ ɪn ðə klaʊdz ɪz tu ivən tə bi nætʃɹəl. mɑɹk ðɪs deɪ ɑn ðə kæləndɝz, sɪlviænə. sʌmθɪŋ əz hæpənd.

"I don't know," Egwene said. "But I welcome the sight of it." She hesitated. "That opening in the clouds is too even to be natural. Mark this day on the calendars, Silviana. Something has happened.

pɝhæps, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, wi ʃæl noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ɪt."

Perhaps, eventually, we shall know the truth of it."

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," sɪlviænə sɛd, lʊkɪŋ aʊt θɹu ðə ɡæp əɡɛn.

"Yes, Mother," Silviana said, looking out through the gap again.

ɛɡwin stʊd wɪð hɝ, ɹæðɝ ðən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɝ stʌɾi ɪmiɾiətli. ɪt fɛlt ɹɪlæksɪŋ tə stɛɹ aʊɾ ət ðət dɪstən laɪt, soʊ wɛlkəmɪŋ ən noʊbəl. "stɔɹmz wɪl sun kʌm," ɪt sim tə seɪ. "bʌt fəɹ naʊ, aɪm hɪɹ."

Egwene stood with her, rather than returning to her study immediately. It felt relaxing to stare out at that distant light, so welcoming and noble. "Storms will soon come," it seemed to say. "But for now, I am here."

aɪm hɪɹ.

I am here.

ət ði ɛn ə taɪm, wən ðə mɛni bɪkʌm wʌn, ðə læst stɔɹm ʃæl ɡæðɝ ɪts æŋɡɹi wɪnz tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ə læn ɔlɹɛɾi daɪɪŋ.

At the end of time, when the many become one, the last storm shall gather its angry winds to destroy a land already dying.

ən əɾ ɪts sɛntɝ, ðə blaɪn mæn ʃæl stæn əpɑn ɪz oʊn ɡɹeɪv.

And at its center, the blind man shall stand upon his own grave.

ðəɹ i ʃæl si əɡɛn, ən wip fəɹ wʌɾ əz bɪn ɹɔt.

There he shall see again, and weep for what has been wrought.

 - fɹəm ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ɛsænɪk saɪkəl. mælhɑvɪʃəz əfɪʃəl tʃɹænzleɪʃən, ɪmpɪɹiəl ɹɛkɝd haʊs ə sindɑɹ, fɔɹθ sɝkəl ʌv ɛləveɪʃən.

 - from The Prophecies of the Dragon, Essanik Cycle. Malhavish's Official Translation, Imperial Record House of Seandar, Fourth Circle of Elevation.

ði ɛn ə ðə twɛlfθ bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɡlɔsɝi eɪ noʊɾ ɑn deɪts ɪn ðɪs ɡlɔsɝi. ðə toʊmən kæləndɝ (dɪvaɪz baɪ toʊmə dɝ ɑməd) wɑz ədɑptəɾ əpɹɑksəmətli tu sɛntʃɝiz æftɝ ðə dɛθ ə ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld (æb). soʊ mɛni ɹɛkɝdz wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ðəɾ ət ðɛɹ ɛn ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmən əbaʊt ði ɪɡzæk jɪɹ ʌndɝ ði oʊl sɪstəm. ə nu kæləndɝ, pɹəpoʊz baɪ tiəm ʌv ɡɑzɹ, sɛləbɹeɪɾəd fɹiɾəm fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk θɹɛɾ ən ɹəkɔɹɾəd itʃ jɪɹ əz ə fɹi jɪɹ (fi).

The End of the Twelfth Book of The Wheel of Time GLOSSARY A Note on Dates in This Glossary. The Toman Calendar (devised by Toma dur Ahmid) was adopted approximately two centuries after the death of the last male Aes Sedai, recording years After the Breaking of the World (AB). So many records were destroyed in the Trolloc Wars that at their end there was argument about the exact year under the old system. A new calendar, proposed by Tiam of Gazar, celebrated freedom from the Trolloc threat and recorded each year as a Free Year (FY).

ðə ɡɑzɝən kæləndɝ ɡeɪnd waɪɾ æksɛptəns wɪðɪn twɛnti jɪɹz æftɝ ðə wɔɹz' ɛnd. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ətɛmptəd tə ɪstæblɪʃ ə nu kæləndɝ beɪst ɑn ðə faʊndɪŋ ə hɪz ɛmpaɪɝ (, fɹəm ðə faʊndɪŋ), bʌɾ oʊnli hɪstɔɹiənz naʊ ɹəfɝ tə ɪt. æftɝ ðə dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ə θɝd kæləndɝ wɑz dɪvaɪz baɪ ɝɛn dɪn dʒubaɪ sɔɹɪŋ ɡʌl, ə skɑlɝ ə ðə si foʊk, ən pɹɑməlɡeɪɾəd baɪ ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ fɛɹiɾ ə tæɹɑbən. ðə fɛɹid kæləndɝ, deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ði ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli dɪsaɪɾɪd ɛn ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ən ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz ə ðə nu ɛɹə (nəbɹæskə), ɪz kɝənli ɪn jus.

The Gazaran Calendar gained wide acceptance within twenty years after the Wars' end. Artur Hawkwing attempted to establish a new calendar based on the founding of his empire (FF, From the Founding), but only historians now refer to it. After the death and destruction of the War of the Hundred Years, a third calendar was devised by Uren din Jubai Soaring Gull, a scholar of the Sea Folk, and promulgated by the Panarch Farede of Tarabon. The Farede Calendar, dating from the arbitrarily decided end of the War of the Hundred Years and recording years of the New Era (NE), is currently in use.

æɛlfɪn: ə ɹeɪs ə biɪŋz, lɑɹdʒli hjumən ɪn əpɪɹəns bʌt wɪð sneɪklaɪk kɛɹəktɝɪstɪks, hu wɪl ɡɪv tʃɹu ænsɝz tə θɹi kwɛstʃənz. wʌtɛvɝ ðə kwɛstʃən, ðɛɹ ænsɝz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz kɝɛkt, ɪf fɹikwənli ɡɪvən ɪn fɔɹmz ðəɾ ɑɹ nɑt klɪɹ, bʌt kwɛstʃənz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ kən bi ɪkstʃɹimli deɪnʒɝəs. ðɛɹ tʃɹu loʊkeɪʃən ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌt ðeɪ kən bi vɪzəɾəd baɪ pæsɪŋ θɹu ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, wʌns ə pəzɛʃən ə min bʌɾ ɪn ɹisən jɪɹz hɛld ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ðət ðeɪ kən ɔlsoʊ bi ɹitʃt baɪ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. ðeɪ spik ði oʊl tʌŋ, mɛnʃən tʃɹiɾiz ən əɡɹiməns ən æsk ɪf ðoʊz ɛntɝɪŋ kæɹi aɪɝn, ɪnstʃɹəməns ə mjuzɪk əɹ dɪvaɪsəz ðət kən meɪk faɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ ɛlfɪn.

Aelfinn: A race of beings, largely human in appearance but with snakelike characteristics, who will give true answers to three questions. Whatever the question, their answers are always correct, if frequently given in forms that are not clear, but questions concerning the Shadow can be extremely dangerous. Their true location is unknown, but they can be visited by passing through a ter'angreal, once a possession of Mayene but in recent years held in the Stone of Tear. There are reports that they can also be reached by entering the Tower of Ghenjei. They speak the Old Tongue, mention treaties and agreements and ask if those entering carry iron, instruments of music or devices that can make fire. See also Eelfinn.

ɑɹæd dumən: ə neɪʃən ɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, kɝənli ɹæk baɪ sɪvəl wɔɹ ən baɪ wɔɹz əɡɛns ðoʊz u hæv dɪklɛɹd fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪts kæpəɾəl ɪz bændɑɹ ɛbən, wɛɹ mɛni ʌv ɪts pipəl əv kʌm fəɹ ɹɛfjudʒ. fuɾ ɪz skɛɹs. ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, ðoʊz u ɑɹ dɪsɛndəd fɹəm ðə noʊbɪləɾi ət ðə taɪm ə ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə neɪʃən, əz əpoʊz tə ðoʊz ɹeɪz leɪɾɝ, ɑɹ noʊn əz ðə blʌdbɔɹn.

Arad Doman: A nation on the Aryth Ocean, currently racked by civil war and by wars against those who have declared for the Dragon Reborn. Its capital is Bandar Eban, where many of its people have come for refuge. Food is scarce. In Arad Doman, those who are descended from the nobility at the time of the founding of the nation, as opposed to those raised later, are known as the bloodborn.

ðə ɹulɝ (kɪŋ əɹ kwin) ɪz ɪlɛktəd baɪ ə kaʊnsəl ə ðə hɛdz ə mɝtʃənt ɡɪlz (ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns), hu ɑɹ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz wɪmən. hi əɹ ʃi mʌs bi fɹəm ðə noʊbəl klæs, nɑt ðə mɝtʃənt, ən ɪz ɪlɛktəd fəɹ laɪf. liɡəli ðə kɪŋ əɹ kwin əz æbsəluɾ əθɔɹəɾi, ɪksɛp ðəɾ i əɹ ʃi kən bi dɪpoʊz baɪ ə θɹi-kɔɹɾɝ voʊɾ ə ðə kaʊnsəl. ðə kɝən ɹulɝ ɪz kɪŋ ælsələm sɑiɾ ælməɾɝ, lɔɹɾ ʌv ælməɾɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs ælməɾɝ. hɪz pɹɛzənt wɛɹəbaʊts ɑɹ mʌtʃ ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn mɪstɝi.

The ruler (king or queen) is elected by a council of the heads of merchant guilds (the Council of Merchants), who are almost always women. He or she must be from the noble class, not the merchant, and is elected for life. Legally the king or queen has absolute authority, except that he or she can be deposed by a three-quarter vote of the Council. The current ruler is King Alsalam Saeed Almadar, Lord of Almadar, High Seat of House Almadar. His present whereabouts are much shrouded in mystery.

ɛɹiə, junəts ʌv: (wʌn) lænd: wʌn ɹɪbən ikwəlz twɛnti peɪsɪz  tɛn peɪsɪz (tuhʌnʒɹəd skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn kɔɹɾ ikwəlz twɛnti peɪsɪz  fɪfti peɪsɪz (wʌnθaʊzən skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn haɪɾ ikwəlz wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz  wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz (tɛnθaʊzən skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn ɹoʊp ikwəlz wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz  wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz (wʌnhʌnʒɹədθaʊzənd skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); fɝs mɑɹtʃ ikwəlz wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz  wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz (wʌnfɔɹθ skwɛɹ maɪl). (tu) klɔθ: wʌn peɪs ikwəlz wʌn peɪs plʌs wʌn hænd  wʌn peɪs plʌs wʌn hænd.

Area, units of: (1) Land: 1 ribbon = 20 paces  10 paces (200 square paces); 1 cord = 20 paces  50 paces (1000 square paces); 1 hide = 100 paces  100 paces (10,000 square paces); 1 rope = 100 paces  1000 paces (100,000 square paces); 1 march = 1000 paces  1000 paces (1/4 square mile). (2) Cloth: 1 pace = 1 pace plus 1 hand  1 pace plus 1 hand.

æʃəmən: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ɡɑɹɾiən" əɹ "ɡɑɹɾiənz," bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ə ɡɑɹɾiən ə dʒʌstəs ən tʃɹuθ. (tu) ðə neɪm ɡɪvən, boʊθ kəlɛktɪvli ən əz ə ɹæŋk, tə ðə mɛn u hæv kʌm tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn ɪn ændɝ, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə lɝn tə tʃænəl. ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ lɑɹdʒli kɑnsəntʃɹeɪts ɑn ðə weɪz ɪn wɪtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ kən bi juzd əz ə wɛpən, ən ɪn ənʌðɝ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ fɹəm ðə jusədʒəz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wʌns ðeɪ lɝn tə siz seɪɾɪn, ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹikwaɪɝd tə pɝfɔɹm ɔl tʃɔɹz ən leɪbɝz wɪð ðə paʊɝ. wən nuli ɛnɹoʊld, ə mæn ɪz tɝmd ə soʊlʒɝ; hi wɛɹz ə pleɪn blæk koʊt wɪð ə haɪ kɑlɝ, ɪn ði ændɔɝən fæʃən. biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə dɛɾəkeɪtəd bɹɪŋz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə sɪlvɝ pɪn, kɔl ðə sɔɹd, ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ə hɪz koʊt. pɹəmoʊʃən tə æʃəmən bɹɪŋz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə dʒɹæɡən pɪn, ɪn ɡoʊld ən ɹɛɾ ɪnæməl, ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ɑpəzət ðə sɔɹd.

Asha'man: (1) In the Old Tongue, "Guardian" or "Guardians," but always a guardian of justice and truth. (2) The name given, both collectively and as a rank, to the men who have come to the Black Tower, near Caemlyn in Andor, in order to learn to channel. Their training largely concentrates on the ways in which the One Power can be used as a weapon, and in another departure from the usages of the White Tower, once they learn to seize saidin, the male half of the Power, they are required to perform all chores and labors with the Power. When newly enrolled, a man is termed a Soldier; he wears a plain black coat with a high collar, in the Andoran fashion. Being raised to Dedicated brings the right to wear a silver pin, called the Sword, on the collar of his coat. Promotion to Asha'man brings the right to wear a Dragon pin, in gold and red enamel, on the collar opposite the Sword.

ɔlðoʊ mɛni wɪmən, ɪnkluɾɪŋ waɪvz, fli wən ðeɪ lɝn ðət ðɛɹ mɛn æktʃəli  kən tʃænəl, ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə mɛn ət ðə blæk taʊɝ ɑɹ mɛɹid, ən ðeɪ juz ə vɝʒən ə ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn tə kɹieɪɾ ə lɪŋk wɪð ðɛɹ waɪvz. ðɪs seɪm bɑnd, ɔltɝd tə kəmpɛl oʊbiɾiəns, hæz ɹisənli bɪn juz tə bɑn kæptʃɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ əz wɛl. səm æʃəmən əv bɪn bɑndəd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔlðoʊ ðə tʃɹədɪʃənəl wɔɹɾɝ bɑn ɪz juzd. ði æʃəmən ɑɹ lɛd baɪ mæzɹim teɪm, hu hæz staɪl hɪmsɛlf ðə l, oʊl tʌŋ fəɹ "liɾɝ."

Although many women, including wives, flee when they learn that their men actually can channel, a fair number of men at the Black Tower are married, and they use a version of the Warder bond to create a link with their wives. This same bond, altered to compel obedience, has recently been used to bond captured Aes Sedai as well. Some Asha'man have been bonded by Aes Sedai, although the traditional Warder bond is used. The Asha'man are led by Mazrim Taim, who has styled himself the M'Hael, Old Tongue for "leader."

bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd: si ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ.

Band of the Red Hand: see Shen an Calhar.

blʌd, ðə: tɝm juz baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə dɛzəɡneɪt ðə noʊbɪləɾi. ðəɹ ɑɹ fɔɹ dɪɡɹiz ə noʊbɪləɾi, tu ʌv ðə haɪ blʌɾ ən tu ʌv ðə loʊ, əɹ lɛsɝ, blʌd. ðə haɪ blʌd lɛt ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɡɹoʊ tə ə lɛŋθ ʌv wʌn ɪntʃ ən ʃeɪv ðə saɪdz ə ðɛɹ hɛdz, livɪŋ ə kɹɛs daʊn ðə sɛntɝ, nɛɹoʊɝ fəɹ mɛn ðən fəɹ wɪmən. ðə lɛŋθ ə ðɪs kɹɛs vɛɹiz əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə fæʃən. ðə loʊ blʌɾ ɔlsoʊ ɡɹoʊ ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz lɔŋ, bʌt ðeɪ ʃeɪv ðə saɪdz ən bæk ə ðə hɛd, livɪŋ wʌɾ əpɪɹz tə bi ə boʊl ə hɛɹ, wɪð ə waɪd teɪl ət ðə bæk əlaʊd tə ɡɹoʊ lɔŋɡɝ, ɔfən tə ðə ʃoʊldɝ fəɹ mɛn əɹ tə ðə weɪs fəɹ wɪmən. ðoʊz ə ðə haɪəs lɛvəl ə ðə haɪ blʌɾ ɑɹ kɔl haɪ leɪɾi əɹ haɪ lɔɹɾ ən lækɝ ðə fɝs tu fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɑn itʃ hænd. ðoʊz ə ðə nɛks lɛvəl ə ðə haɪ blʌɾ ɑɹ kɔl sɪmpli lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi ən lækɝ oʊnli ðə neɪlz ə ðə fɔɹfɪŋɝz. ðoʊz ə ðə loʊ blʌɾ ɔlsoʊ ɑɹ kɔl sɪmpli leɪɾi əɹ lɔɹd, bʌt ðoʊz ə ðə haɪɝ ɹæŋk lækɝ ðə neɪlz ə ðə læs tu fɪŋɡɝz ɑn itʃ hænd, waɪl ðoʊz ɑn ðə loʊəs lɛvəl lækɝ oʊnli ðə neɪlz ə ðə lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝz. ði ɛmpɹɛs ən ɪmiɾiət mɛmbɝz ə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli ʃeɪv ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪntaɪɝli ən lækɝ ɔl ə ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz wʌn kən bi ɹeɪz tə ðə blʌɾ əz wɛl əz bɔɹn tə ɪt, ən ðɪs ɪz fɹikwənli ə ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ aʊtstændɪŋ əkɑmplɪʃmən əɹ sɝvəs tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ.

Blood, the: Term used by the Seanchan to designate the nobility. There are four degrees of nobility, two of the High Blood and two of the low, or lesser, Blood. The High Blood let their fingernails grow to a length of one inch and shave the sides of their heads, leaving a crest down the center, narrower for men than for women. The length of this crest varies according to fashion. The low Blood also grow their fingernails long, but they shave the sides and back of the head, leaving what appears to be a bowl of hair, with a wide tail at the back allowed to grow longer, often to the shoulder for men or to the waist for women. Those of the highest level of the High Blood are called High Lady or High Lord and lacquer the first two fingernails on each hand. Those of the next level of the High Blood are called simply Lord or Lady and lacquer only the nails of the forefingers. Those of the low Blood also are called simply Lady or Lord, but those of the higher rank lacquer the nails of the last two fingers on each hand, while those on the lowest level lacquer only the nails of the little fingers. The Empress and immediate members of the Imperial family shave their heads entirely and lacquer all of their fingernails One can be raised to the Blood as well as born to it, and this is frequently a reward for outstanding accomplishment or service to the Empire.

bɹaʊn ədʒɑ kaʊnsəl: ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ ɪz hɛɾəd baɪ ə kaʊnsəl ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ən ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə kɝən hɛɾ ə ðə kaʊnsəl ɪz dʒɛsi biləl ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ; ði ʌðɝ mɛmbɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən ɔl ə ðoʊz ɪn ðə ɹɛbəl kæmp ɑɹ ənnoʊn.

Brown Ajah Council: The Brown Ajah is headed by a council instead of an individual Aes Sedai. The current head of the council is Jesse Bilal in the White Tower; the other members in the White Tower and all of those in the rebel camp are unknown.

kæləndɝ: ðəɹ ɑɹ tɛn deɪz tə ðə wik, twɛntieɪt deɪz tə ðə mʌnθ ən θɝtin mʌnθs tə ðə jɪɹ. sɛvɹəl fis deɪz ɑɹ nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛni mʌnθ; ðiz ɪnklud sʌndeɪ (ðə lɔŋɡəs deɪ ʌv ðə jɪɹ), ðə fist ə θæŋksɡɪvɪŋ (wʌns ɛvɹi fɔɹ jɪɹz ət ðə spɹɪŋ ikwənɑks) ən ðə fist ʌv ɔl soʊlz sælveɪʃən, ɔlsoʊ kɔld ɔl soʊlz deɪ (wʌns ɛvɹi tɛn jɪɹz ət ði ɔɾəm ikwənɑks). waɪl ðə mʌnθs əv neɪmz (teɪʃəm, dʒumɑɹə, seɪbən, eɪn, ədɑɹ, sævən, ɑmɑdeɪn, tæməz, meɪaɪɡdəl, kɔɹən, ʃɔldin, nɛzæn ən dænu), ðiz ɑɹ sɛldəm juzd ɪksɛpt ɪn əfɪʃəl dɑkjəməns ən baɪ əfɪʃəlz. fəɹ moʊs pipəl, juzɪŋ ðə sizənz ɪz ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf.

calendar: There are 10 days to the week, 28 days to the month and 13 months to the year. Several feast days are not part of any month; these include Sunday (the longest day of the year), the Feast of Thanksgiving (once every four years at the spring equinox) and the Feast of All Souls Salvation, also called All Souls Day (once every ten years at the autumn equinox). While the months have names (Taisham, Jumara, Saban, Aine, Adar, Saven, Amadaine, Tammaz, Maigdhal, Choren, Shaldine, Nesan and Danu), these are seldom used except in official documents and by officials. For most people, using the seasons is good enough.

kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ ædlɔɹnə bæstin ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən maɪɹɛl bɛɹɛŋɡɑɹi əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəl fækʃən.

Captain-General: The title given to the head of the Green Ajah. This position is currently held by Adelorna Bastine in the White Tower, and Myrelle Berengari among the rebel faction.

tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt: səsaɪəɾi ʌv stʃɹɪkt əsɛɾɪk bɪlifs, oʊɪŋ əlidʒəns tə noʊ neɪʃən ən dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz. faʊndəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz baɪ lɑthɛɹ mæntəlɝ tə pɹɑsələtaɪz əɡɛnst ən ɪnkɹis ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ ɪvɑlv dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ɪndə ə kəmplitli mɪlətɛɹi səsaɪəɾi. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ bɪlifs, ən sɝɾən ðəɾ oʊnli ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ən ðə ɹaɪt. ðeɪ kənsɪɾɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɛni hu səpɔɹɾ əm tə bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz. noʊn dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli əz waɪtkloʊks, ə neɪm ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz dɪspaɪz, ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹmɝli hɛdkɔɹɾɝd ɪn æmədɔɹ, ɑmɑdɪʃiə, bʌt wɝ fɔɹst aʊt wən ðə sintʃæn kɑŋkɝd ðə sɪɾi. ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd bɪkeɪm lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ æftɝ i kɪld imən vɑldə ɪn ə duəl fəɹ əsɔltɪŋ ɪz stɛpmʌðɝ, mɔɹɡeɪs. vɑldəz dɛθ pɹədust ə skɪzəm ɪn ði ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, wɪð ɡɑləd liɾɪŋ wʌn fækʃən, ən ɹɑɾəm əsunɑwə, haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ ə ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt, liɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɑn ə fild ʌv waɪt. si ɔlsoʊ kwɛstʃənɝz.

Children of the Light: Society of strict ascetic beliefs, owing allegiance to no nation and dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One and the destruction of all Darkfriends. Founded during the War of the Hundred Years by Lothair Mantelar to proselytize against an increase in Darkfriends, they evolved during the war into a completely military society. They are extremely rigid in their beliefs, and certain that only they know the truth and the right. They consider Aes Sedai and any who support them to be Darkfriends. Known disparagingly as Whitecloaks, a name they themselves despise, they were formerly headquartered in Amador, Amadicia, but were forced out when the Seanchan conquered the city. Galad Damodred became Lord Captain Commander after he killed Eamon Valda in a duel for assaulting his stepmother, Morgase. Valda's death produced a schism in the organization, with Galad leading one faction, and Rhadam Asunawa, High Inquisitor of the Hand of the Light, leading the other. Their sign is a golden sunburst on a field of white. See also Questioners.

kɑməntɛɹi ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən: ə bʊk baɪ seɪdʒiɪs ʌv wɪtʃ lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn.

Commentary on the Dragon: A book by Sajius of which little is known.

kɑmpɹihɛnsɪv dɪskʌʃən ə pɹi-bɹeɪkɪŋ ɹɛlɪks, eɪ: ə bʊk ʌv wɪtʃ lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn (ʌðɝ ðən ɪts taɪɾəl).

Comprehensive Discussion of Pre-Breaking Relics, A: A book of which little is known (other than its title).

kɔɝɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə ɹɪtɝn." ðə neɪm ɡɪvən baɪ ðə sintʃæn boʊθ tə ðə fliɾ ə θaʊzənz ə ʃɪps ən tə ðə hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz ə soʊlʒɝz, kɹæfsmən ən ʌðɝz kæɹid baɪ ðoʊz ʃɪps, hu keɪm bɪhaɪn ðə fɔɹʌnɝz tə ɹikleɪm ðə lænz stoʊlən fɹəm ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz dɪsɛndəns. ðə kɔɝɪn ɪz lɛd baɪ kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl lunəl ɡælɡən. si ɔlsoʊ heɪlin, ɹaɪædʒɛl.

Corenne: In the Old Tongue, "the Return." The name given by the Seanchan both to the fleet of thousands of ships and to the hundreds of thousands of soldiers, craftsmen and others carried by those ships, who came behind the Forerunners to reclaim the lands stolen from Artur Hawkwing's descendants. The Corenne is led by Captain-General Lunal Galgan. See also Hailene, Rhyagelle.

kwəndɪlɝ: ə səpoʊzədli ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl sʌbstəns kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɛni noʊn fɔɹs juzd ɪn ən ətɛmp tə bɹeɪk ɪt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɪz əbzɔɹbd, meɪkɪŋ kwəndɪlɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ. ɔlðoʊ ðə meɪkɪŋ ə kwəndɪlɝ wɑz θɔt lɔs fɝɛvɝ, nu ɑbʒɛkts meɪd fɹəm ɪɾ əv sɝfɪst. ɪts ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz hɑɹtstoʊn.

cuendillar: A supposedly indestructible substance created during the Age of Legends. Any known force used in an attempt to break it, including the One Power, is absorbed, making cuendillar stronger. Although the making of cuendillar was thought lost forever, new objects made from it have surfaced. It is also known as heartstone.

kɝənsi: æftɝ mɛni sɛntʃɝiz ə tʃɹeɪd, ðə stændɝd tɝmz fəɹ kɔɪnz ɑɹ ðə seɪm ɪn ɛvɹi lænd:

currency: After many centuries of trade, the standard terms for coins are the same in every land:

kɹaʊnz (ðə lɑɹdʒəs kɔɪn ɪn saɪz), mɑɹks ən pɛniz. kɹaʊnz ən mɑɹks kən bi mɪntɪɾ ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ, waɪl pɛniz kən bi sɪlvɝ əɹ kɑpɝ, ðə læst ɔfən kɔl sɪmpli ə kɑpɝ. ɪn dɪfɹən lænz, haʊɛvɝ, ðiz kɔɪnz ɑɹ ə dɪfɹən saɪzəz ən weɪts. ivən ɪn wʌn neɪʃən, kɔɪnz ə dɪfɹən saɪzəz ən weɪts əv bɪn mɪntɪd baɪ dɪfɹən ɹulɝz. kəz ə tʃɹeɪd, ðə kɔɪnz ə mɛni neɪʃənz kən bi faʊn ɔlmoʊst ɛniwɛɹ, ən fəɹ ðət ɹizən, bæŋkɝz, mʌnilɛndɝz ən mɝtʃəns ɔl jus skeɪlz tə dətɝmən ðə vælju ʌv ɛni ɡɪvən kɔɪn. ivən lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə kɔɪnz ɑɹ weɪd.

crowns (the largest coin in size), marks and pennies. Crowns and marks can be minted of gold or silver, while pennies can be silver or copper, the last often called simply a copper. In different lands, however, these coins are of different sizes and weights. Even in one nation, coins of different sizes and weights have been minted by different rulers. Because of trade, the coins of many nations can be found almost anywhere, and for that reason, bankers, moneylenders and merchants all use scales to determine the value of any given coin. Even large numbers of coins are weighed.

ðə hɛviəs kɔɪnz kʌm fɹəm ændɝ ən tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ɪn ðoʊz tu pleɪsəz ðə ɹɛləɾɪv væljuz ɑɹ: tɛn kɑpɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ pɛni; wʌnhʌnʒɹəd sɪlvɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ mɑɹk; tɛn sɪlvɝ mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn

The heaviest coins come from Andor and Tar Valon, and in those two places the relative values are: 10 copper pennies = 1 silver penny; 100 silver pennies = 1 silver mark; 10 silver marks = 1

sɪlvɝ kɹaʊn; tɛn sɪlvɝ kɹaʊnz ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl mɑɹk; tɛn ɡoʊl mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl kɹaʊn. baɪ kɑntʃɹæst, ɪn ɔltɑɹə, wɛɹ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ kɔɪnz kənteɪn lɛs ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ, ðə ɹɛləɾɪv væljuz ɑɹ: tɛn kɑpɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn

silver crown; 10 silver crowns = 1 gold mark; 10 gold marks = 1 gold crown. By contrast, in Altara, where the larger coins contain less gold or silver, the relative values are: 10 copper pennies = 1

sɪlvɝ pɛni; twɛntiwʌn sɪlvɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ mɑɹk; twɛnti sɪlvɝ mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ kɹaʊn; twɛnti sɪlvɝ kɹaʊnz ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl mɑɹk; twɛnti ɡoʊl mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl kɹaʊn.

silver penny; 21 silver pennies = 1 silver mark; 20 silver marks = 1 silver crown; 20 silver crowns = 1 gold mark; 20 gold marks = 1 gold crown.

ði oʊnli peɪpɝ kɝənsi ɪz "lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts," wɪtʃ ɑɹ ɪʃud baɪ bæŋkɝz, ɡɛɹəntiɪŋ tə pɹizɛn ə sɝɾən əmaʊn ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ wən ðə lɛɾɝ-ʌv-ɹaɪts ɪz pɹizɛntəd. kəz ə ðə lɔŋ dɪstənsəz bɪtwin sɪɾiz, ðə lɛŋθ ə taɪm niɾəd tə tʃɹævəl fɹəm wʌn tə ənʌðɝ ən ðə dɪfəkəltiz ə tʃɹænzækʃənz ət lɔŋ dɪstəns, ə lɛɾɝ-ʌv-ɹaɪts meɪ bi æksɛptɪɾ ət fʊl vælju ɪn ə sɪɾi nɪɹ tə ðə bæŋk wɪtʃ ɪʃuɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt meɪ oʊnli bi æksɛptɪɾ əɾ ə loʊɝ vælju ɪn ə sɪɾi fɑɹðɝ əweɪ. dʒɛnɝəli, sʌmwʌn ɪntɛndɪŋ tə bi tʃɹævlɪŋ fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm wɪl kæɹi wʌn əɹ mɔɹ lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fəɹ kɔɪn wən niɾəd. lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts ɑɹ juʒəwəli æksɛptɪɾ oʊnli baɪ bæŋkɝz əɹ mɝtʃəns, ən wəd nɛvɝ bi juzd ɪn ʃɑps.

The only paper currency is "letters-of-rights," which are issued by bankers, guaranteeing to present a certain amount of gold or silver when the letter-of-rights is presented. Because of the long distances between cities, the length of time needed to travel from one to another and the difficulties of transactions at long distance, a letter-of-rights may be accepted at full value in a city near to the bank which issued it, but it may only be accepted at a lower value in a city farther away. Generally, someone intending to be traveling for a long time will carry one or more letters-of-rights to exchange for coin when needed. Letters-of-rights are usually accepted only by bankers or merchants, and would never be used in shops.

dækoʊvæl: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wʌn u ɪz oʊnd," əɹ "pɝsən u ɪz pɹɑpɝɾi." (tu) əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ðə tɝm ɔfən juzd, əlɔŋ wɪð "pɹɑpɝɾi," fəɹ sleɪvz. sleɪvɝi hæz ə lɔŋ ən ənjuʒəwəl hɪstɝi əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, wɪð sleɪvz hævɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə ɹaɪz tə pəzɪʃənz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ ən oʊpən əθɔɹəɾi, ɪnkluɾɪŋ əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ðoʊz u ɑɹ fɹi. ɪts ɔlsoʊ pɑsəbəl fəɹ ðoʊz ɪn pəzɪʃənz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ tə bi ɹədus tə dækoʊvæl. si ɔlsoʊ sɔɪhɪn.

da'covale: (1) In the Old Tongue, "one who is owned," or "person who is property." (2) Among the Seanchan, the term often used, along with "property," for slaves. Slavery has a long and unusual history among the Seanchan, with slaves having the ability to rise to positions of great power and open authority, including authority over those who are free. It is also possible for those in positions of great power to be reduced to da'covale. See also so'jhin.

dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ə ðə sintʃæn ɛmpaɪɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ boʊθ hjumənz ən oʊɡiɝ. ðə hjumən mɛmbɝz ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹɾ ɑɹ ɔl dækoʊvæl, bɔɹn əz pɹɑpɝɾi ən tʃoʊzən waɪl jʌŋ tə sɝv ði ɛmpɹɛs, huz pɝsənəl pɹɑpɝɾi ðeɪ ɑɹ. fənæɾɪkəli lɔɪəl ən fɪɹsli pɹaʊd, ðeɪ ɔfən dɪspleɪ ðə ɹeɪvənz tætuɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ðə mɑɹk ʌv ə dækoʊvæl ə ði ɛmpɹɛs. ði oʊɡiɝ mɛmbɝz ɑɹ noʊn əz ɡɑɹɾənɝz, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt dækoʊvæl. ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz ɑɹ əz fɪɹsli lɔɪəl əz ðə hjumən dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ðoʊ, ən ɑɹ ivən mɔɹ fɪɹd.

Deathwatch Guards, the: The elite military formation of the Seanchan Empire, including both humans and Ogier. The human members of the Deathwatch Guard are all da'covale, born as property and chosen while young to serve the Empress, whose personal property they are. Fanatically loyal and fiercely proud, they often display the ravens tattooed on their shoulders, the mark of a da'covale of the Empress. The Ogier members are known as Gardeners, and they are not da'covale. The Gardeners are as fiercely loyal as the human Deathwatch Guards, though, and are even more feared.

hjumən əɹ oʊɡiɝ, ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz nɑɾ oʊnli ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə daɪ fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs ən ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, bʌt bɪliv ðət ðɛɹ laɪvz ɑɹ ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ði ɛmpɹɛs, tə bi dɪspoʊzd ʌv əz ʃi wɪʃɪz.

Human or Ogier, the Deathwatch Guards not only are ready to die for the Empress and the Imperial family, but believe that their lives are the property of the Empress, to be disposed of as she wishes.

ðɛɹ hɛlməts ən ɑɹmɝ ɑɹ lækɝɾ ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin (soʊ dɑɹk ðəɾ ɪts ɔfən mɪsteɪkənli kɔl blæk)

Their helmets and armor are lacquered in dark green (so dark that it is often mistakenly called black)

ən blʌd-ɹɛd, ðɛɹ ʃilz ɑɹ lækɝd blæk ən ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, spɪɹz, æksiz ən hælbɝdz kæɹi blæk tæsəlz. si ɔlsoʊ dækoʊvæl.

and blood-red, their shields are lacquered black and their swords, spears, axes and halberds carry black tassels. See also da'covale.

dɛlvɪŋ: (wʌn) juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə daɪəɡnoʊs fɪzɪkəl kəndɪʃən ən ɪlnəs. (tu) faɪndɪŋ dəpɑzɪts ə mɛɾəl ɔɹz wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðət ðɪs əz lɔŋ bɪn ə lɔst əbɪləɾi əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ əkaʊn fəɹ ðə neɪm bɪkʌmɪŋ ətætʃt tə ənʌðɝ əbɪləɾi.

Delving: (1) Using the One Power to diagnose physical condition and illness. (2) Finding deposits of metal ores with the One Power. That this has long been a lost ability among Aes Sedai may account for the name becoming attached to another ability.

dɪpɑzətɔɹi: ə dɪvɪʒən ə ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi. ðəɹ ɑɹ twɛlv pʌblɪkli noʊn dəpɑzətɔɹiz, itʃ hævɪŋ bʊks ən ɹɛkɝdz pɝteɪnɪŋ tə ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ sʌbʒɪkt, əɹ tə ɹɪleɪɾɪd sʌbʒɪkts. eɪ θɝtinθ dɪpɑzətɔɹi, noʊn oʊnli tə səm ɛɛs sədaɪ, kənteɪnz sikɹət dɑkjəməns, ɹɛkɝdz ən hɪstɝiz wɪtʃ meɪ bi æksɛst oʊnli baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ðə kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz, ən ðə sɪɾɝz ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, baɪ ðət hændfʊl ə laɪbɹɛɹiənz u meɪnteɪn ðə dɪpɑzətɔɹi.

Depository: A division of the Tower Library. There are twelve publicly known Depositories, each having books and records pertaining to a particular subject, or to related subjects. A Thirteenth Depository, known only to some Aes Sedai, contains secret documents, records and histories which may be accessed only by the Amyrlin Seat, the Keeper of the Chronicles, and the Sitters in the Hall of the Tower. And, of course, by that handful of librarians who maintain the depository.

dɝmɝæt-: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "mæstɝ hænlɝ." (tu) əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ðə pɹifɪks əplaɪd tə ɪndəkeɪɾ ə sinjɝ ən haɪli skɪl hænlɝ ʌv wʌn ə ði ɛɡzɑɾɪks, wʌn u tʃɹeɪnz ʌðɝz, əz ɪn dɝmɝətʃɹeɪkən. dɝmɝæt kən əv ə fɛɹli haɪ soʊʃəl stæɾəs, ðə haɪəst ʌv ɔl hɛl baɪ dɝsʌldəm, ðə tʃɹeɪnɝz ə sʌldəm, hu ɹæŋk wɪð fɛɹli haɪ mɪlətɛɹi ɔfəsɝz. si ɔlsoʊ mɔɝæt-.

der'morat-: (1) In the Old Tongue, "master handler." (2) Among the Seanchan, the prefix applied to indicate a senior and highly skilled handler of one of the exotics, one who trains others, as in der'morat'raken. Der'morat can have a fairly high social status, the highest of all held by der'sul'dam, the trainers of sul'dam, who rank with fairly high military officers. See also morat-.

ɛkoʊz ə hɪz daɪnəsti: ə bʊk ʌv wɪtʃ lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn.

Echoes of His Dynasty: A book of which little is known.

ɛlfɪn: ə ɹeɪs ə biɪŋz, lɑɹdʒli hjumən ɪn əpɪɹəns bʌt wɪð fɑkslaɪk kɛɹəktɝɪstɪks, hu wɪl ɡɹæn θɹi wɪʃɪz, ɔlðoʊ ðeɪ æsk fəɹ ə pɹaɪs ɪn ɹɪtɝn. ɪf ðə pɝsən æskɪŋ dʌz nɑt nəɡoʊʃieɪɾ ə pɹaɪs, ði ɛlfɪn tʃuz ɪt. ðə moʊs kɑmən pɹaɪs ɪn sətʃ sɝkəmstænsəz ɪz dɛθ, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl fʊlfɪl ðɛɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən, ɔlðoʊ ðə mænɝ ɪn wɪtʃ ðeɪ fʊlfɪl ɪts sɛldəm ðə mænɝ ðə wʌn æskɪŋ ɪkspɛks. ðɛɹ tʃɹu loʊkeɪʃən ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə vɪzəɾ əm baɪ minz ʌv ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət wɑz loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn ɹɪɾiən. ðət tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz teɪkən baɪ mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd tə kɛɹhin, wɛɹ ɪt wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd. ɪts ɔlsoʊ ɹipɔɹɾəd ðət ðeɪ meɪ bi ɹitʃt baɪ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. ðeɪ æsk ðə seɪm kwɛstʃənz əz ði æɛlfɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ faɪɝ, aɪɝn ən mjuzɪkəl ɪnstʃɹəməns.

Eelfinn: A race of beings, largely human in appearance but with foxlike characteristics, who will grant three wishes, although they ask for a price in return. If the person asking does not negotiate a price, the Eelfinn choose it. The most common price in such circumstances is death, but they still fulfill their part of the bargain, although the manner in which they fulfill it is seldom the manner the one asking expects. Their true location is unknown, but it was possible to visit them by means of a ter'angreal that was located in Rhuidean. That ter'angreal was taken by Moiraine Damodred to Cairhien, where it was destroyed. It is also reported that they may be reached by entering the Tower of Ghenjei. They ask the same questions as the Aelfinn regarding fire, iron and musical instruments.

si ɔlsoʊ æɛlfɪn.

See also Aelfinn.

fɔlɪŋ ʃeɪl: ə hɪstɝi ʌv wɪtʃ lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn.

Falling Shale: A history of which little is known.

fɛl, hɹɪd: ði ɔθɝ ə ɹizən ən ənɹisən ən ʌðɝ bʊks. fɛl wɑz ə stuɾənt (æn titʃɝ)

Fel, Herid: The author of Reason and Unreason and other books. Fel was a student (and teacher)

ʌv hɪstɝi ən fəlɑsəfi ət ði əkæɾəmi ʌv kɛɹhin. hi wɑz dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ɪz stʌɾi tɔɹn lɪm fɹəm lɪm.

of history and philosophy at the Academy of Cairhien. He was discovered in his study torn limb from limb.

fɝst ɹizənɝ: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ fɛɹən nhɝən, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. fɛɹən sədaɪ ɪz wʌn ʌv oʊnli tu ədʒɑ hɛdz tə sɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ət pɹɛzənt.

First Reasoner: The title given to the head of the White Ajah. This position is currently held by Ferane Neheran, an Aes Sedai in the White Tower. Ferane Sedai is one of only two Ajah heads to sit in the Hall of the Tower at present.

fɝst səlɛktɝ: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə blu ədʒɑ. ðə fɝst səlɛktɝ ɪz kɝənli ənnoʊn, ɔlðoʊ ɪts səspɛktəd ðət ləleɪn əkɑʃi fɪlz ðɪs pəzɪʃən.

First Selector: The title given to the head of the Blue Ajah. The First Selector is currently unknown, although it is suspected that Lelaine Akashi fills this position.

fɝst wivɝ: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ swænə dʒɹeɪɡən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. swænə sədaɪ ɪz wʌn ʌv oʊnli tu ədʒɑ hɛdz tə sɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ət pɹɛzənt. əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹoʊmændə kæsɪn hoʊlz ðɪs pəzɪʃən.

First Weaver: The title given to the head of the Yellow Ajah. This position is currently held by Suana Dragand in the White Tower. Suana Sedai is one of only two Ajah heads to sit in the Hall of the Tower at present. Among the rebel Aes Sedai, Romanda Cassin holds this position.

fɔɹsɪŋ; fɔɹst: wən sʌmwʌn wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl hændəlz əz mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ðeɪ kən oʊvɝ lɔŋ pɪɹiədz ə taɪm ən tʃænəlz kəntɪnjuəli, ðeɪ lɝn fæstɝ ən ɡeɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ mɔɹ ɹæpədli. ðɪs ɪz kɔl fɔɹsɪŋ, əɹ biɪŋ fɔɹst, baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu æbdʒʊɝ ðə pɹæktəs wɪð nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd kəz ə ðə deɪnʒɝ ə dɛθ əɹ biɪŋ bɝn aʊt.

Forcing; forced: When someone with the ability to channel handles as much of the One Power as they can over long periods of time and channels continually, they learn faster and gain strength more rapidly. This is called forcing, or being forced, by Aes Sedai, who abjure the practice with novices and Accepted because of the danger of death or being burned out.

fɔɹʌnɝz, ðə: si heɪlin.

Forerunners, the: See Hailene.

fɔɹseɪkən, ðə: ðə neɪm ɡɪvən tə θɝtin paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɛn ən wɪmən boʊθ, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ən wɝ tʃɹæpt ɪn ðə silɪŋ ə ðə bɔɹ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. waɪl ɪts lɔŋ bɪn bɪliv ðət ðeɪ əloʊn əbændən ðə laɪt dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ɪn fækt ʌðɝz dɪɾ əz wɛl; ðiz θɝtin wɝ oʊnli ðə haɪəst-ɹæŋkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðə fɔɹseɪkən (hu kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə tʃoʊzən) ɑɹ sʌmwʌt ɹədust ɪn nʌmbɝ sɪns ðɛɹ əweɪkənɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹɛzən deɪ. səm ə ðoʊz kɪld əv bɪn ɹiɪnkɑɹneɪɾɪd ɪn nu bɑɾiz.

Forsaken, the: The name given to thirteen powerful Aes Sedai, men and women both, who went over to the Shadow during the Age of Legends and were trapped in the sealing of the Bore into the Dark One's prison. While it has long been believed that they alone abandoned the Light during the War of the Shadow, in fact others did as well; these thirteen were only the highest-ranking among them. The Forsaken (who call themselves the Chosen) are somewhat reduced in number since their awakening in the present day. Some of those killed have been reincarnated in new bodies.

heɪlin: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "fɔɹʌnɝz," əɹ "ðoʊz u kʌm bɪfɔɹ." ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə ðə mæsɪv ɛkspədɪʃənɛɹi fɔɹs sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə skaʊɾ aʊt ðə lænz wɛɹ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wʌns ɹuld. ɝɪdʒənəli ʌndɝ ðə kəmæn ə ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ, ɪts naʊ bɪn sʌbsumd ɪndə ðə kɔɝɪn. si kɔɝɪn, ɹaɪædʒɛl.

Hailene: In the Old Tongue, "Forerunners," or "Those Who Come Before." The term applied by the Seanchan to the massive expeditionary force sent across the Aryth Ocean to scout out the lands where Artur Hawkwing once ruled. Originally under the command of the High Lady Suroth, it has now been subsumed into the Corenne. See Corenne, Rhyagelle.

hænd: ɪn sintʃæn, hæn ɹəfɝz tə ə pɹaɪmɛɹi əsɪstən əɹ wʌn ʌv ə haɪɝɑɹki ʌv ɪmpɪɹiəl fʌŋkʃənɛɹiz. eɪ hæn ə ði ɛmpɹɛs ɪz ə ðə fɝst ɹæŋk, ən lɛsɝ hænz wɪl bi faʊn ət loʊɝ ɹæŋks. səm hænz ɑpɝeɪɾ ɪn sikɹət, sətʃ əz ðoʊz u ɡaɪd ðə sikɝz ən lɪsənɝz; ʌðɝz ɑɹ noʊn ən dɪspleɪ ðɛɹ ɹæŋk baɪ wɛɹɪŋ ði əpɹoʊpɹiət nʌmbɝ ʌv ɡoʊldən hænz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ.

Hand: In Seanchan, Hand refers to a primary assistant or one of a hierarchy of Imperial functionaries. A Hand of the Empress is of the First Rank, and Lesser Hands will be found at lower ranks. Some Hands operate in secret, such as those who guide the Seekers and Listeners; others are known and display their rank by wearing the appropriate number of golden hands embroidered on their clothing.

hænlən, dɑvd: eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ, hu wɑz kæptʃɝd wɪð leɪɾi ʃieɪn, tʃɛzməl ɛmɹi, ɛlʒɹɪθ ɑndɑɹ, təmeɪl kɪndɝəd, fæljən boʊɾə ən mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn.

Hanlon, Daved: A Darkfriend, also known as Doilin Mellar, who was captured with Lady Shiaine, Chesmal Emry, Eldrith Jhondar, Temaile Kinderode, Falion Bhoda and Marillin Gemalphin.

ðeɪ ɑɹ kɝənli biɪŋ hɛl pɹɪznɝ ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ʌv ændɝ.

They are currently being held prisoner in the Royal Palace of Andor.

hɛd klɝk: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ sɹæntʃə kɑlvaɪn ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Head Clerk: The title given to the head of the Gray Ajah. This position is currently held by Serancha Colvine in the White Tower.

hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt kaʊnsəl ə θɝtin: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ ɑlviɛɝɪn fɹaɪɾən.

Head of the Great Council of Thirteen: The title given to the head of the Black Ajah. This position is currently held by Alviarin Freidhen.

hɑɹt: ðə beɪsɪk junəɾ ʌv ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən ɪn ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ɪn ɪfɛkt, ə sɛl. ə hɑɹt kənsɪsts ə θɹi sɪstɝz u noʊ itʃ ʌðɝ, wɪð itʃ mɛmbɝ ə ðə hɑɹt noʊɪŋ wʌn ədɪʃənəl sɪstɝ ə ðə blæk u ɪz ənnoʊn tə ði ʌðɝ tu ʌv əɹ hɑɹt.

heart: The basic unit of organization in the Black Ajah. In effect, a cell. A heart consists of three sisters who know each other, with each member of the heart knowing one additional sister of the Black who is unknown to the other two of her heart.

haɪəst: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ tsutɑmə ɹæθ.

Highest: The title given to the head of the Red Ajah. This position is currently held by Tsutama Rath.

ɪluməneɪɾɝz, ɡɪld ʌv: ə səsaɪəɾi ðət hɛl ðə sikɹəɾ ə meɪkɪŋ faɪɹwɝks. ɪt ɡɑɹɾəd ðɪs sikɹət vɛɹi kloʊsli, ivən tə ði ɪkstɛn ə duɪŋ mɝɾɝ tə pɹətɛkt ɪt. ðə ɡɪld ɡeɪn ɪts neɪm fɹəm ðə ɡɹæn dɪspleɪz, kɔld ɪluməneɪʃənz, ðəɾ ɪt pɹəvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹulɝz ən səmtaɪmz fəɹ ɡɹeɪɾɝ lɔɹdz.

Illuminators, Guild of: A society that held the secret of making fireworks. It guarded this secret very closely, even to the extent of doing murder to protect it. The Guild gained its name from the grand displays, called Illuminations, that it provided for rulers and sometimes for greater lords.

lɛsɝ faɪɹwɝks wɝ soʊl fəɹ jus baɪ ʌðɝz, bʌt wɪð daɪɹ wɔɹnɪŋz ə ðə dɪzæstɝ ðət kəd ɹɪzʌl fɹəm ətɛmptɪŋ tə lɝn wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðɛm. ðə ɡɪld wʌns hæd tʃæptɝ haʊsəz ɪn kɛɹhin ən tæntʃəkoʊ, bʌt boʊθ ɑɹ naʊ dɪstʃɹɔɪd. ɪn ədɪʃən, ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə ɡɪld ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ɹɪzɪstɪd ði ɪnveɪʒən baɪ ðə sintʃæn ən wɝ meɪd dækoʊvæl, ən ðə ɡɪld əz sətʃ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪɡzɪsts.

Lesser fireworks were sold for use by others, but with dire warnings of the disaster that could result from attempting to learn what was inside them. The Guild once had chapter houses in Cairhien and Tanchico, but both are now destroyed. In addition, the members of the Guild in Tanchico resisted the invasion by the Seanchan and were made da'covale, and the Guild as such no longer exists.

haʊɛvɝ, ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl ɪluməneɪɾɝz stɪl ɪɡzɪst aʊtsaɪɾ ə sintʃæn ɹul ən wɝk tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət ðə ɡɪld wɪl bi ɹɪmɛmbɝd. si ɔlsoʊ dækoʊvæl.

However, individual Illuminators still exist outside of Seanchan rule and work to make sure that the Guild will be remembered. See also da'covale.

ɪʃɑɹə: ðə fɝs kwin ʌv ændɝ (sɝkə fi naɪnnaɪnfɔɹwʌnzɪɹoʊɾuzɪɹoʊ). ət ðə dɛθ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, ɪʃɑɹə kənvɪnst əɹ hʌzbənd, wʌn ə hɔkwɪŋz fɔɹmoʊs dʒɛnɝəlz, tə ɹeɪz ðə sidʒ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən əkʌmpəni hɝ tə keɪɛmlɪn wɪð əz mɛni soʊlʒɝz əz i kəd bɹeɪk əweɪ fɹəm ði ɑɹmi. wɛɹ ʌðɝz tʃɹaɪd tə siz ðə hoʊl ə hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ ən feɪld, ɪʃɑɹə tʊk ə fɝm hoʊld ɑn ə smɔl pɑɹɾ ən səksiɾəd. tədeɪ, nɪɹli ɛvɹi noʊbəl haʊs ɪn ændɝ kənteɪnz səm ʌv ɪʃɑɹəz blʌd, ən ðə ɹaɪt tə kleɪm ðə laɪən θɹoʊn dɪpɛnz boʊθ ɑn dɝɛk dɪsɛn fɹəm əɹ ən ɑn ðə nʌmbɝ ə laɪnz ə kənɛkʃən tə hɝ ðət kən bi ɪstæblɪʃt.

Ishara: The first Queen of Andor (circa FY 9941020). At the death of Artur Hawkwing, Ishara convinced her husband, one of Hawkwing's foremost generals, to raise the siege of Tar Valon and accompany her to Caemlyn with as many soldiers as he could break away from the army. Where others tried to seize the whole of Hawkwing's empire and failed, Ishara took a firm hold on a small part and succeeded. Today, nearly every noble House in Andor contains some of Ishara's blood, and the right to claim the Lion Throne depends both on direct descent from her and on the number of lines of connection to her that can be established.

kɛnsɑɾə: ən ɛɹiə ʌv sintʃæn ðəɾ ɪz pɑpjəleɪɾəd baɪ lɛs-ðæn-sɪvəlaɪz hɪl tʃɹaɪbz. ðiz tʃɹaɪbz faɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, əz də ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl fæmliz wɪðɪn ðə tʃɹaɪbz. itʃ tʃɹaɪb əz ɪts oʊn kʌstəmz ən tæbuz, ðə læɾɝ ʌv wɪtʃ ɔfən meɪk noʊ sɛns tə ɛniwʌn aʊtsaɪd ðət tʃɹaɪb. moʊst ə ðə tʃɹaɪbzmɪn əvɔɪd ðə mɔɹ sɪvəlaɪzd ɹɛzəɾənts ə sintʃæn.

Kaensada: An area of Seanchan that is populated by less-than-civilized hill tribes. These tribes fight a great deal among themselves, as do individual families within the tribes. Each tribe has its own customs and taboos, the latter of which often make no sense to anyone outside that tribe. Most of the tribesmen avoid the more civilized residents of Seanchan.

læns-kæptən: ɪn moʊs lænz, noʊbəlwɪmən də nɑt pɝsənəli lɛd ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn ɪndə bæɾəl ʌndɝ nɔɹməl sɝkəmstænsəz. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ haɪɝ ə pɹəfɛʃənəl soʊlʒɝ, ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ə kɑmənɝ, hu ɪz ɹispɑnsəbəl boʊθ fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ən liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn. dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ðə lænd, ðɪs mæn kən bi kɔld ə læns-kæptən, sɔɹd-kæptən, mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs əɹ mæstɝ ə ðə lænsɪz. ɹumɝz ə kloʊsɝ ɹileɪʃənʃɪps ðən leɪɾi ən sɝvən ɔfən spɹɪŋ ʌp, pɝhæps ɪnɛvəɾəbli. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹu.

Lance-Captain: In most lands, noblewomen do not personally lead their armsmen into battle under normal circumstances. Instead, they hire a professional soldier, almost always a commoner, who is responsible both for training and leading their armsmen. Depending on the land, this man can be called a Lance-Captain, Sword-Captain, Master of the Horse or Master of the Lances. Rumors of closer relationships than Lady and servant often spring up, perhaps inevitably. Sometimes they are true.

lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ðə: ə lɑɹdʒ mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən, ɔl ɪnfəntʃɹi, ɡɪvɪŋ əlidʒəns tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, tʃɹeɪn baɪ dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ əlɔŋ laɪnz wɝkt aʊt baɪ hɪmsɛlf ən mæt kɔθən, laɪnz wɪtʃ dɪpɑɹt ʃɑɹpli fɹəm ðə juʒəwəl ɛmplɔɪmən ə fʊt. waɪl mɛni mɛn sɪmpli wɔk ɪn tə vɑləntɪɹ, lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə ðə lidʒən ɑɹ skupt ʌp baɪ ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz fɹəm ðə blæk taʊɝ, hu fɝst ɡæðɝ ɔl ə ðə mɛn ɪn ən ɛɹiə hu ɑɹ wɪlɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən oʊnli æftɝ teɪkɪŋ əm θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn wɪnoʊ aʊt ðoʊz u kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl. ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ, baɪ fɑɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ nʌmbɝ, ɑɹ sɛn tə bæʃɪɹz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ kæmps.

Legion of the Dragon, the: A large military formation, all infantry, giving allegiance to the Dragon Reborn, trained by Davram Bashere along lines worked out by himself and Mat Cauthon, lines which depart sharply from the usual employment of foot. While many men simply walk in to volunteer, large numbers of the Legion are scooped up by recruiting parties from the Black Tower, who first gather all of the men in an area who are willing to follow the Dragon Reborn, and only after taking them through gateways near Caemlyn winnow out those who can be taught to channel. The remainder, by far the greater number, are sent to Bashere's training camps.

lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv: tɛn ɪntʃəz ikwəlz wʌn fʊt; θɹi fiɾ ikwəlz wʌn peɪs; tu peɪsɪz ikwəlz wʌn spæn; wʌnθaʊzən spænz ikwəlz wʌn maɪl; fɔɹ

Length, units of: 10 inches = 1 foot; 3 feet = 1 pace; 2 paces = 1 span; 1000 spans = 1 mile; 4

maɪlz  wʌn liɡ.

miles = 1 league.

lɪsənɝz: eɪ sintʃæn spaɪ ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən. ɔlmoʊst ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə haʊshoʊld ʌv ə sintʃæn noʊbəl, mɝtʃən əɹ bæŋkɝ meɪ bi ə lɪsənɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ dækoʊvæl əkeɪʒənəli, ðoʊ sɛldəm sɔɪhɪn. ðeɪ teɪk noʊ æktɪv ɹoʊl, mɪɹli wɑtʃɪŋ, lɪsnɪŋ ən ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ. ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑɹ sɛn tə lɛsɝ hænz u kəntʃɹoʊl boʊθ əm ən ðə sikɝz ən dɪsaɪd wʌt ʃəd bi pæst ɑn tə ðə sikɝz fəɹ fɝðɝ ækʃən. si ɔlsoʊ sikɝz, hænd.

Listeners: A Seanchan spy organization. Almost anyone in the household of a Seanchan noble, merchant or banker may be a Listener, including da'covale occasionally, though seldom so'jhin. They take no active role, merely watching, listening and reporting. Their reports are sent to Lesser Hands who control both them and the Seekers and decide what should be passed on to the Seekers for further action. See also Seekers, Hand.

mɛɹəθdəmeɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðoʊz u mʌs bi liʃt," ən ɔlsoʊ "wʌn u mʌs bi liʃt." ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə ɛni wʊmən keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ u hæz nɑt bɪn kɑlɝɾ əz ə deɪmeɪn.

marath'damane: In the Old Tongue, "those who must be leashed," and also "one who must be leashed." The term applied by the Seanchan to any woman capable of channeling who has not been collared as a damane.

mɑɹtʃ: si ɛɹiə, junəts ʌv.

march: see Area, units of.

mɑɹks ən ɹɪmɑɹks: ə hɪstɝi ʌv wɪtʃ lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn.

Marks and Remarks: A history of which little is known.

mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs: si læns-kæptən.

Master of the Horse: See Lance-Captain.

mæstɝ ə ðə lænsɪz: si læns-kæptən.

Master of the Lances: See Lance-Captain.

mɛɾɪteɪʃənz ɑn ðə kɪnlɪŋ fleɪm: ə hɪstɝi dilɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹaɪz ə vɛɹiəs æmɪɝlənz.

Meditations on the Kindling Flame: A history dealing with the rise of various Amyrlins.

mɛlɝ, dɔɪlɪn: si hænlən, dɑvd.

Mellar, Doilin: See Hanlon, Daved.

mɛɝeɪɾɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə bɹʌðɝləs." ðə neɪm ədɑptəd, əz ə səsaɪəɾi, baɪ ðoʊz il u əbændən klæn ən sɛpt ən wɛn tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kəz ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ æksɛpt ɹænd ælθɹ, ə wɛtləndɝ, əz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, əɹ kəz ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɪz ɹɛvəleɪʃənz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə hɪstɝi ən ɔɹədʒɪnz ə ði il. dɛzɝɾɪŋ klæn ən sɛp fəɹ ɛni ɹizən ɪz ənæθəmə əmʌŋ ði il; ðɛɹfɔɹ ðɛɹ oʊn wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ ənwɪlɪŋ tə teɪk əm ɪn, ən ðeɪ fɔɹm ðɪs səsaɪəɾi, ðə bɹʌðɝləs.

Mera'din: In the Old Tongue, "the Brotherless." The name adopted, as a society, by those Aiel who abandoned clan and sept and went to the Shaido because they could not accept Rand al'Thor, a wetlander, as the Car'a'carn, or because they refused to accept his revelations concerning the history and origins of the Aiel. Deserting clan and sept for any reason is anathema among the Aiel; therefore their own warrior societies among the Shaido were unwilling to take them in, and they formed this society, the Brotherless.

mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd: eɪ kɛɹhinɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ. lɔŋ pɹəzum dɛd. tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn hæz, haʊɛvɝ, ɹɪvil ðə ɹɪsiɾ ʌv ə lɛɾɝ pɝpɔɹɾɪŋ tə bi fɹəm hɝ. ɪts ɹipɹədus hɪɹ:

Moiraine Damodred: A Cairhienin Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah. Long presumed dead. Thom Merrilin has, however, revealed the receipt of a letter purporting to be from her. It is reproduced here:

maɪ dɪɹəs tɑm, ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni wɝdz aɪ wəd laɪk tə ɹaɪt tə ju, wɝdz fɹəm maɪ hɑɹt, bʌɾ aɪ hæv pʊt ðɪs ɔf kəz aɪ nu ðəɾ aɪ mʌst, ən naʊ ðəɹ ɪz lɪɾəl taɪm. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni θɪŋz aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə lɛst aɪ bɹɪŋ dɪzæstɝ, bʌt wʌɾ aɪ kæn, aɪ wɪl. hid kɛɹfəli wʌɾ aɪ seɪ. ɪn ə ʃɔɹt waɪl əl ɡoʊ daʊn tə ðə dɑks, ən ðəɹ əl kənfɹʌn lænfɝ. haʊ kən aɪ noʊ ðæt? ðət sikɹət bɪlɔŋz tə ʌðɝz. səfaɪs ɪt ðəɾ aɪ noʊ, ən lɛt ðət fɹknoʊlɪdʒ stæn əz pɹuf fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ʌv wʌɾ aɪ seɪ.

My dearest Thom, There are many words I would like to write to you, words from my heart, but I have put this off because I knew that I must, and now there is little time. There are many things I cannot tell you lest I bring disaster, but what I can, I will. Heed carefully what I say. In a short while I will go down to the docks, and there I will confront Lanfear. How can I know that? That secret belongs to others. Suffice it that I know, and let that foreknowledge stand as proof for the rest of what I say.

wən jə ɹəsiv ðɪs, jəl bi toʊl ðəɾ aɪm dɛd. ɔl wɪl bɪliv ðæt. aɪm nɑt dɛd, ən ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ aɪ ʃæl lɪv tə maɪ əpɔɪntəd jɪɹz. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ meɪ bi ðət jə ən mæt kɔθən ən ənʌðɝ, ə mæn aɪ də nɑt noʊ, wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɛskju mi. meɪ, aɪ seɪ kəz ɪt meɪ bi ðət jəl nɑɾ əɹ kænɑt, əɹ kəz mæt meɪ ɹəfjuz. hi dʌz nɑt hoʊl mi ɪn ði əfɛkʃən jə sim tə, ən hiz ɪz ɹizənz wɪtʃ i noʊ daʊt θɪŋks ɑɹ ɡʊd. ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ, ɪt mʌs bi oʊnli jə ən mæt ən wʌn ʌðɝ. mɔɹ wɪl min dɛθ fəɹ ɔl. fjuɝ wɪl min dɛθ fəɹ ɔl.

When you receive this, you will be told that I am dead. All will believe that. I am not dead, and it may be that I shall live to my appointed years. It also may be that you and Mat Cauthon and another, a man I do not know, will try to rescue me. May, I say because it may be that you will not or cannot, or because Mat may refuse. He does not hold me in the affection you seem to, and he has his reasons which he no doubt thinks are good. If you try, it must be only you and Mat and one other. More will mean death for all. Fewer will mean death for all.

ivən ɪf jə kʌm oʊnli wɪð mæt ən wʌn ʌðɝ, dɛθ ɔlsoʊ meɪ kʌm. aɪ hæv sin jə tʃɹaɪ ən daɪ, wʌn əɹ tu əɹ ɔl θɹi. aɪ hæv sin maɪsɛlf daɪ ɪn ði ətɛmpt. aɪ hæv sin ɔl ʌv əs lɪv ən daɪ əz kæptɪvz.

Even if you come only with Mat and one other, death also may come. I have seen you try and die, one or two or all three. I have seen myself die in the attempt. I have seen all of us live and die as captives.

ʃəd jə dɪsaɪd tə meɪk ði ətɛmpt ɛniweɪ, jʌŋ mæt noʊz ðə weɪ tə faɪn mi, jɛt jə mʌs nɑt ʃoʊ hɪm ðɪs lɛɾɝ əntɪl i æsks əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðəɾ ɪz ə ði ʌtmoʊst ɪmpɔɹɾəns. hi mʌs noʊ nʌθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz ɪn ðɪs lɛɾɝ əntɪl i æsks. ɪvɛns mʌs pleɪ aʊɾ ɪn sɝɾən weɪz, wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑsts.

Should you decide to make the attempt anyway, young Mat knows the way to find me, yet you must not show him this letter until he asks about it. That is of the utmost importance. He must know nothing that is in this letter until he asks. Events must play out in certain ways, whatever the costs.

ɪf jə si læn əɡɛn, tɛl ɪm ðəɾ ɔl ə ðɪs ɪz fəɹ ðə bɛst. hɪz dɛstəni fɑloʊz ə dɪfɹən pæθ fɹəm maɪn. aɪ wɪʃ ɪm ɔl hæpinəs wɪð nɪneɪiv.

If you see Lan again, tell him that all of this is for the best. His destiny follows a different path from mine. I wish him all happiness with Nynaeve.

ə faɪnəl pɔɪnt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt jə noʊ əbaʊt ðə ɡeɪm ə sneɪks ən fɑksəz. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən hid.

A final point. Remember what you know about the game of Snakes and Foxes. Remember, and heed.

ɪts taɪm, ən aɪ mʌs də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn.

It is time, and I must do what must be done.

meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin jə ən ɡɪv jə dʒɔɪ, maɪ dɪɹəs tɑm, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt wi ɛvɝ si wʌn ənʌðɝ əɡɛn.

May the Light illumine you and give you joy, my dearest Thom, whether or not we ever see one another again.

mɔɪɹeɪn mɑnjəməns pæst: ə hɪstɝi ʌv wɪtʃ lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn.

Moiraine Monuments Past: A history of which little is known.

mɔɝæt-: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "hænlɝ." əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ɪts juz fəɹ ðoʊz u hændəl ɛɡzɑɾɪks, sətʃ əz mɔɹətʃɹeɪkən, ə ɹeɪkən hænlɝ əɹ ɹaɪɾɝ, ɔlsoʊ ɪnfɔɹməli kɔld ə flaɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ dɝmɝæt-.

morat-: In the Old Tongue, "handler." Among the Seanchan, it is used for those who handle exotics, such as morat'raken, a raken handler or rider, also informally called a flier. See also der'morat-.

pɛlæɾioʊz: ɔθɝ ə pɛlæɾioʊz' pɑndɝɪŋz.

Pelateos: Author of Pelateos' Ponderings.

pɹɑpɝ teɪmɪŋ ə paʊɝ, ðə: ə hɪstɝi ʌv wɪtʃ lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn.

Proper Taming of Power, The: A history of which little is known.

pɹɑfət, ðə: mɔɹ fɔɹməli, ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. wʌns noʊn əz mæsimə dɑɡɝ, ə ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝ, hi ʌndɝwɛn ə ɹɛvəleɪʃən ən dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ i hæd bɪn kɔl tə spɹɛd ðə wɝɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz ɹibɝθ. hi bɪliv ðət nʌθɪŋ - nʌθɪŋ! - wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz ðə laɪt meɪd flɛʃ ən biɪŋ ɹɛɾi wən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kɔld, ən i ən ɪz fɑloʊɝz wəd juz ɛni minz tə fɔɹs ʌðɝz tə sɪŋ ðə ɡlɔɹiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðoʊz u ɹəfjuzd wɝ mɑɹk fəɹ dɛθ, ən ðoʊz u wɝ sloʊ maɪt faɪn ðɛɹ hoʊmz ən ʃɑps bɝn ən ðɛmsɛlvz flɑɡd. fɔɹseɪkɪŋ ɛni neɪm bʌt "ðə pɹɑfət," hi bɹɔt keɪɑs tə mʌtʃ ʌv ɡildən ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə, lɑɹdʒ pɑɹts ʌv wɪtʃ i kəntʃɹoʊld, ɔlðoʊ wɪð ɪm ɡɔn, ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ ɹiɪstæblɪʃɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ ɪn ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən ðə kɹaʊn haɪ kaʊnsəl ɪn ɡildən. hi dʒɔɪnd wɪð pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, hu wɑz sɛn tə bɹɪŋ ɪm tə ɹænd, ænd, fəɹ ɹizənz ənnoʊn, steɪd wɪð ɪm ivən ðoʊ ðɪs dɪleɪɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi wɑz fɑloʊd baɪ mɛn ən wɪmən ə ðə loʊəst sɔɹt; ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt soʊ wən ðeɪ wɝ pʊld ɪn baɪ hɪz kɝɪzmə, ðeɪ bɪkeɪm soʊ ʌndɝ ɪz ɪnfluəns. hi daɪɾ ʌndɝ mɪstɪɹiəs sɝkəmstænsəz.

Prophet, the: More formally, the Prophet of the Lord Dragon. Once known as Masema Dagar, a Shienaran soldier, he underwent a revelation and decided that he had been called to spread the word of the Dragon's Rebirth. He believed that nothing - nothing! - was more important than acknowledging the Dragon Reborn as the Light made flesh and being ready when the Dragon Reborn called, and he and his followers would use any means to force others to sing the glories of the Dragon Reborn. Those who refused were marked for death, and those who were slow might find their homes and shops burned and themselves flogged. Forsaking any name but "the Prophet," he brought chaos to much of Ghealdan and Amadicia, large parts of which he controlled, although with him gone, the Seanchan are reestablishing order in Amadicia and the Crown High Council in Ghealdan. He joined with Perrin Aybara, who was sent to bring him to Rand, and, for reasons unknown, stayed with him even though this delayed his going to the Dragon Reborn. He was followed by men and women of the lowest sort; if they were not so when they were pulled in by his charisma, they became so under his influence. He died under mysterious circumstances.

kwinz ɡɑɹd, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ɪn ændɝ. ɪn pistaɪm ðə ɡɑɹɾ ɪz ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ əphoʊldɪŋ ðə kwinz lɔ ən kipɪŋ ðə pis əkɹɔs ændɝ. ðə junəfɔɹm ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹɾ ɪnkludz ə ɹɛɾ ʌndɝkoʊt, ɡlimɪŋ meɪl ən pleɪɾ ɑɹmɝ, ə bɹɪljən ɹɛd kloʊk ən ə kɑnɪkəl hɛlmət wɪð ə bɑɹd vaɪzɝ. haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ ɔfəsɝz wɛɹ nɑts ə ɹæŋk ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən ɡoʊldən laɪən-hɛd spɝz. ə ɹisən ədɪʃən tə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹɾ ɪz ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz pɝsənəl bɑɾiɡɑɹd, wɪtʃ ɪz kəmpoʊzd ɪntaɪɝli ʌv wɪmən sɪns ði ɝɛst ʌv ɪts fɔɹmɝ kæptən, dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ. ðiz ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɛɹ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪlæbɹət junəfɔɹmz ðən ðɛɹ meɪl kaʊntɝpɑɹts, ɪnkluɾɪŋ bɹɔd-bɹɪm hæts wɪð waɪt plumz, ɹɛd-lækɝd bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts tʃɹɪmd ɪn waɪɾ ən leɪs-ɛdʒ sæʃɪz bɛɹɪŋ ðə waɪt laɪən ʌv ændɝ.

Queen's Guard, the: The elite military formation in Andor. In peacetime the Guard is responsible for upholding the Queen's law and keeping the peace across Andor. The uniform of the Queen's Guard includes a red undercoat, gleaming mail and plate armor, a brilliant red cloak and a conical helmet with a barred visor. High-ranking officers wear knots of rank on their shoulder and golden lion-head spurs. A recent addition to the Queen's Guard is the Daughter-Heir's personal bodyguard, which is composed entirely of women since the arrest of its former captain, Doilin Mellar. These Guardswomen wear much more elaborate uniforms than their male counterparts, including broad-brimmed hats with white plumes, red-lacquered breastplates and helmets trimmed in white and lace-edged sashes bearing the White Lion of Andor.

kwɛstʃənɝz, ðə: ən ɔɹɾɝ wɪðɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. ðeɪ ɹəfɝ tə ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt - ðeɪ ɪntɛnsli dɪslaɪk biɪŋ kɔl kwɛstʃənɝz - ən ðɛɹ əvaʊd pɝpəsəz ɑɹ tə dɪskʌvɝ ðə tʃɹuθ ɪn dɪspjəteɪʃənz ən ənkʌvɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɪn ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ tʃɹuθ ən ðə laɪt, ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mɛθəɾ ʌv ɪnkwaɪɹi ɪz tɔɹtʃɝ; ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mænɝ ɪz ðət ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ɔlɹɛɾi ən mʌst oʊnli meɪk ðɛɹ vɪktəm kənfɛs tə ɪt. ət taɪmz ðeɪ ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪntaɪɝli sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd, wɪtʃ kəmænz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɪz ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ, ət pɹɛzən ɹɑɾəm əsunɑwə, hu sɪts ɑn ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd. æftɝ ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd kɪld lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ vɑldə ən əsum vɑldəz pəzɪʃən, ðəɹ wɑz ə skɪzəm ɪn ði ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, wɪð ɡɑləd liɾɪŋ wʌn fækʃən, ən əsunɑwə liɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə blʌd-ɹɛd ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk.

Questioners, the: An order within the Children of the Light. They refer to themselves as the Hand of the Light - they intensely dislike being called Questioners - and their avowed purposes are to discover the truth in disputations and uncover Darkfriends. In the search for truth and the Light, their normal method of inquiry is torture; their normal manner is that they know the truth already and must only make their victim confess to it. At times they act as if they are entirely separate from the Children and the Council of the Anointed, which commands the Children. The head of the Questioners is the High Inquisitor, at present Rhadam Asunawa, who sits on the Council of the Anointed. After Galad Damodred killed Lord Captain Commander Valda and assumed Valda's position, there was a schism in the organization, with Galad leading one faction, and Asunawa leading the other. Their sign is a blood-red shepherd's crook.

ɹɛdʒɹmz: soʊlʒɝz ə ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd, hu hæv bɪn tʃoʊzən fəɹ tɛmpɝɛɹi pəlis duɾi tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz ə ðə bæn kɑz noʊ tʃɹʌbəl əɹ dæmədʒ ɪn ə taʊn əɹ vɪlədʒ wɛɹ ðə bæn əz stɑpt. soʊ neɪm bɪkɔz, waɪl ɑn duɾi, ðeɪ wɛɹ vɛɹi bɹɔd ɹɛɾ ɑɹmbænz ðət ɹitʃ fɹəm kʌf tə ɛlboʊ. juʒəwəli tʃoʊzən fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə moʊst ɪkspɪɹiənst ən ɹɪlaɪəbəl mɛn.

Redarms: Soldiers of the Band of the Red Hand, who have been chosen for temporary police duty to make sure that other soldiers of the Band cause no trouble or damage in a town or village where the Band has stopped. So named because, while on duty, they wear very broad red armbands that reach from cuff to elbow. Usually chosen from among the most experienced and reliable men.

sɪns ɛni dæmədʒəz mʌs bi peɪd fəɹ baɪ ðə mɛn sɝvɪŋ əz ɹɛdʒɹmz, ðeɪ wɝk hɑɹd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɔl ɪz kwaɪəɾ ən pisfəl. ə nʌmbɝ ə fɔɹmɝ ɹɛdʒɹmz wɝ tʃoʊzən tə əkʌmpəni mæt kɔθən tə ɛbu dɑɹ. si ɔlsoʊ ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ.

Since any damages must be paid for by the men serving as Redarms, they work hard to make sure all is quiet and peaceful. A number of former Redarms were chosen to accompany Mat Cauthon to Ebou Dar. See also Shen an Calhar.

ɹɪtɝn, ðə: si kɔɝɪn.

Return, the: See Corenne.

ɹaɪædʒɛl, ðə: oʊl tʌŋ fəɹ "ðoʊz u kʌm hoʊm." ənʌðɝ neɪm fəɹ ðə sintʃæn u hæv ɹɪtɝn tə ðə lænz wʌns hɛl baɪ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. si ɔlsoʊ kɔɝɪn, heɪlin.

Rhyagelle, the: Old Tongue for "Those Who Come Home." Another name for the Seanchan who have returned to the lands once held by Artur Hawkwing. See also Corenne, Hailene.

seɪdʒiɪs: ɔθɝ ə kɑməntɛɹi ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən.

Sajius: Author of Commentary on the Dragon.

sindɑɹ: ði ɪmpɪɹiəl kæpəɾəl ə sintʃæn, loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn ðə nɔɹθist ə ðə sintʃæn kɑntənənt. ɪts ɔlsoʊ ðə lɑɹdʒəst sɪɾi ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝ. æftɝ ðə dɛθ ʌv ɛmpɹɛs ɹɑɾənən, ɪt dɪsɛndəɾ ɪndə keɪɑs.

Seandar: The Imperial capital of Seanchan, located in the northeast of the Seanchan continent. It is also the largest city in the Empire. After the death of Empress Radhanan, it descended into chaos.

sikɝz: mɔɹ fɔɹməli, sikɝz fəɹ tʃɹuθ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ə pəlisslæʃspaɪ ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən ə ðə sintʃæn ɪmpɪɹiəl θɹoʊn. ɔlðoʊ moʊst sikɝz ɑɹ dækoʊvæl ən ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, ðeɪv waɪd-ɹeɪnʒɪŋ paʊɝz. ivən wʌn ə ðə blʌd kən bi ɝɛstəd fəɹ feɪljɝ tə ænsɝ ɛni kwɛstʃən pʊt baɪ ə sikɝ, əɹ fəɹ feɪljɝ tə koʊɑpɝeɪt fʊli wɪð ə sikɝ, ðɪs læs dɪfaɪn baɪ ðə sikɝz ðɛmsɛlvz, sʌbʒɪkt oʊnli tə ɹivju baɪ ði ɛmpɹɛs. ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑɹ sɛn tə lɛsɝ hænz, hu kəntʃɹoʊl boʊθ əm ən ðə lɪsənɝz. moʊst sikɝz fil ðət ðə hænz də nɑt pæs ɑn əz mʌtʃ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əz ðeɪ ʃʊd. ənlaɪk ðə lɪsənɝz', ðə sikɝz' ɹoʊl ɪz æktɪv. ðoʊz sikɝz u ɑɹ dækoʊvæl ɑɹ mɑɹkt ɑn iðɝ ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ə ɹeɪvən ən ə taʊɝ. ənlaɪk ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, sikɝz ɑɹ sɛldəm iɡɝ tə ʃoʊ ðɛɹ ɹeɪvənz, ɪn pɑɹt kəz ɪt nəsɛsəteɪts ɹɪvilɪŋ u ən wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ. si ɔlsoʊ hænd, lɪsənɝz.

Seekers: More formally, Seekers for Truth, they are a police/spy organization of the Seanchan Imperial Throne. Although most Seekers are da'covale and the property of the Imperial family, they have wide-ranging powers. Even one of the Blood can be arrested for failure to answer any question put by a Seeker, or for failure to cooperate fully with a Seeker, this last defined by the Seekers themselves, subject only to review by the Empress. Their reports are sent to Lesser Hands, who control both them and the Listeners. Most Seekers feel that the Hands do not pass on as much information as they should. Unlike the Listeners', the Seekers' role is active. Those Seekers who are da'covale are marked on either shoulder with a raven and a tower. Unlike the Deathwatch Guards, Seekers are seldom eager to show their ravens, in part because it necessitates revealing who and what they are. See also Hand, Listeners.

siməsiv: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "loʊɝɾ aɪz," əɹ "daʊnkæst aɪz." əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, tə seɪ ðət wʌn əz "bɪkʌm siməsiv" minz ðət wʌn əz "lɔs feɪs." si ɔlsoʊ seɪaɪtɑɹ.

sei'mosiev: In the Old Tongue, "lowered eyes," or "downcast eyes." Among the Seanchan, to say that one has "become sei'mosiev" means that one has "lost face." See also sei'taer.

seɪaɪtɑɹ: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "stʃɹeɪɾ aɪz," əɹ "lɛvəl aɪz." əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ɪt ɹəfɝz tə ɑnɝ əɹ feɪs, tə ði əbɪləɾi tə mit sʌmwʌnz aɪz. ɪts pɑsəbəl tə "bi" əɹ "hæv" seɪaɪtɑɹ, minɪŋ ðət wʌn əz ɑnɝ ən feɪs, ən ɔlsoʊ tə "ɡeɪn" əɹ "luz" seɪaɪtɑɹ. si ɔlsoʊ siməsiv.

sei'taer: In the Old Tongue, "straight eyes," or "level eyes." Among the Seanchan, it refers to honor or face, to the ability to meet someone's eyes. It is possible to "be" or "have" sei'taer, meaning that one has honor and face, and also to "gain" or "lose" sei'taer. See also sei'mosiev.

ʃɑɹə: ə mɪstɪɹiəs læn tə ði ist ə ði il weɪst wɪtʃ ɪz ðə sɔɹs ə sɪlk ən aɪvɝi, əmʌŋ ʌðɝ tʃɹeɪd ɡʊdz. ðə læn ɪz pɹətɛktəd boʊθ baɪ ɪnhɑspəɾəbəl nætʃɹəl fitʃɝz ən baɪ mæn- meɪd wɔlz. lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn əbaʊt ʃɑɹə, əz ðə pipəl ə ðət lænd wɝk tə kip ðɛɹ kʌltʃɝ sikɹət.

Shara: A mysterious land to the east of the Aiel Waste which is the source of silk and ivory, among other trade goods. The land is protected both by inhospitable natural features and by man- made walls. Little is known about Shara, as the people of that land work to keep their culture secret.

ðə ʃɝɑnz dɪnaɪ ðət ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz tʌtʃt ðɛm, dɪspaɪɾ il steɪtməns tə ðə kɑntʃɹɛɹi. ðeɪ dɪnaɪ nɑlədʒ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ətɛmptəɾ ɪnveɪʒən, dɪspaɪt ði əkaʊns ʌv aɪwɪtnəsɪz fɹəm ðə si foʊk. ðə lɪɾəl ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ðəɾ əz likt aʊt ɹɪvilz ðət ðə ʃɝɑnz ɑɹ ɹul baɪ ə sɪŋɡəl æbsəlut mɑnɑɹk, ə boʊn ɪf ə wʊmən ən ə boʊɾ ɪf ə mæn. ðət mɑnɑɹk ɹulz fəɹ ɪɡzækli sɛvən jɪɹz, ðən daɪz. ðə ɹul ðən pæsəz tə ðə meɪɾ ə ðət ɹulɝ, hu ɹulz fəɹ sɛvən jɪɹz ən ðən daɪz. ðɪs pæɾɝn əz ɹɪpiɾɪd ɪtsɛlf sɪns ðə taɪm ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ðə ʃɝɑnz bɪliv ðət ðə dɛθs ɑɹ ðə "wɪl ə ðə pæɾɝn."

The Sharans deny that the Trolloc Wars touched them, despite Aiel statements to the contrary. They deny knowledge of Artur Hawkwing's attempted invasion, despite the accounts of eyewitnesses from the Sea Folk. The little information that has leaked out reveals that the Sharans are ruled by a single absolute monarch, a Sh'boan if a woman and a Sh'botay if a man. That monarch rules for exactly seven years, then dies. The rule then passes to the mate of that ruler, who rules for seven years and then dies. This pattern has repeated itself since the time of the Breaking of the World. The Sharans believe that the deaths are the "Will of the Pattern."

ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃænlɝz ɪn ʃɑɹə, noʊn əz ði aɪɑd, hu ɑɹ tætuɾ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz ət bɝθ. ðə wɪmən ə ði aɪɑɾ ɛnfɔɹs ði aɪɑd lɔz stʃɹɪnʒəntli. ə sɛkʃuəl ɹileɪʃənʃɪp bɪtwin aɪɑɾ ən nɑn-aɪɑɾ ɪz pʌnɪʃəbəl baɪ dɛθ fəɹ ðə nɑn-aɪɑd, ən ði aɪɑɾ ɪz ɔlsoʊ ɛksəkjuɾəd ɪf fɔɹs ɑn ɪz əɹ əɹ pɑɹt kən bi pɹuvən. ɪf ə tʃaɪld ɪz bɔɹn ə ðə junjən, ɪts lɛft ɪkspoʊz tə ði ɛləməns, ən daɪz.

There are channelers in Shara, known as the Ayyad, who are tattooed on their faces at birth. The women of the Ayyad enforce the Ayyad laws stringently. A sexual relationship between Ayyad and non-Ayyad is punishable by death for the non-Ayyad, and the Ayyad is also executed if force on his or her part can be proven. If a child is born of the union, it is left exposed to the elements, and dies.

meɪl aɪɑɾ ɑɹ juzd əz bɹiɾɪŋ stɑk oʊnli. ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd ɪn ɛni fæʃən, nɑɾ ivən haʊ tə ɹiɾ əɹ ɹaɪt, ən wən ðeɪ ɹitʃ ðɛɹ twɛnti-fɝs jɪɹ əɹ bɪɡɪn tə tʃænəl, wɪtʃɛvɝ kʌmz fɝst, ðeɪ ɑɹ kɪld ən ðə bɑɾi kɹimeɪɾɪd. səpoʊzədli, ði aɪɑd tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ oʊnli ət ðə kəmæn ə ðə boʊn əɹ boʊt, hu ɪz ɔlweɪz sɝaʊndəd baɪ aɪɑd wɪmən.

Male Ayyad are used as breeding stock only. They are not educated in any fashion, not even how to read or write, and when they reach their twenty-first year or begin to channel, whichever comes first, they are killed and the body cremated. Supposedly, the Ayyad channel the One Power only at the command of the Sh'boan or Sh'botay, who is always surrounded by Ayyad women.

ivən ðə neɪm ə ðə læn ɪz ɪn daʊt. ðə neɪɾɪvz əv bɪn noʊn tə kɔl ɪt mɛni dɪfɹənt neɪmz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ʃəmɑɹə, koʊɾənsɪn, toʊmɑkə, kiɡɑli ən ʃɪbujə.

Even the name of the land is in doubt. The natives have been known to call it many different names, including Shamara, Co'dansin, Tomaka, Kigali and Shibouya.

ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd." (wʌn) ə lɛdʒəndɛɹi ɡɹup ə hɪɹoʊz u hæd mɛni ɛksplɔɪts, faɪnəli daɪɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪfɛns ə meɪnɛðɝən wən ðət lænd wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. (tu) ə mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən pʊt təɡɛðɝ ɔlmoʊs baɪ æksəɾənt baɪ mæt kɔθən ən ɔɹɡənaɪzd əlɔŋ ðə laɪnz ə mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹsɪz dʊɹɪŋ wʌɾ ɪz kənsɪɾɝd ðə haɪɾ ə ðə mɪlətɛɹi ɑɹts, ðə deɪz ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ən ðə sɛntʃɝiz ɪmiɾiətli pɹisiɾɪŋ.

Shen an Calhar: In the Old Tongue, "the Band of the Red Hand." (1) A legendary group of heroes who had many exploits, finally dying in the defense of Manetheren when that land was destroyed during the Trolloc Wars. (2) A military formation put together almost by accident by Mat Cauthon and organized along the lines of military forces during what is considered the height of the military arts, the days of Artur Hawkwing and the centuries immediately preceding.

sɪsnɛɹə, dɑɹlɪn: eɪ haɪ lɔɹɾ ɪn tɛɹ, hi wɑz fɔɹmɝli ɪn ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Sisnera, Darlin: A High Lord in Tear, he was formerly in rebellion against the Dragon Reborn.

æftɝ sɝvɪŋ fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt pɪɹiəɾ əz stuɝɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn tɛɹ, hi wɑz tʃoʊzən tə bi ðə fɝs kɪŋ ə tiɹ.

After serving for a short period as Steward of the Dragon Reborn in Tear, he was chosen to be the first king of Tear.

sneɪks ən fɑksəz: ə ɡeɪm ðəɾ ɪz mʌtʃ lʌv baɪ tʃɪlʒɹən əntɪl ðeɪ mətʃʊɹ ɪnʌf tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪt kən nɛvɝ bi wʌn wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə ɹulz. ɪts pleɪd wɪð ə bɔɹd ðəɾ əz ə wɛb ə laɪnz wɪð æɹoʊz ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ dɝɛkʃən. ðəɹ ɑɹ tɛn dɪsks ɪŋkt wɪð tʃɹaɪæŋɡəlz tə ɹɛpɹəzɛn ðə fɑksəz, ən tɛn dɪsks ɪŋkt wɪð weɪvi laɪnz tə ɹɛpɹəzɛn ðə sneɪks. ðə ɡeɪm ɪz bɪɡʌn baɪ seɪɪŋ, "kɝədʒ tə stʃɹɛŋθən, faɪɝ tə blaɪnd, mjuzɪk tə dæzəl, aɪɝn tə baɪnd," waɪl dɪskɹaɪbɪŋ ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl wɪð ə weɪvi laɪn θɹu ɪt wɪð wʌnz hænd. daɪs ɑɹ ɹoʊl tə dətɝmən muvz fəɹ ðə pleɪɝz ən ðə sneɪks ən fɑksəz. ɪf ə sneɪk əɹ fɑks lænz ɑn ə pleɪɝz pis, hiz aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪm, ən əz lɔŋ əz ðə ɹulz ɑɹ fɑloʊd, ðɪs ɔlweɪz hæpənz.

Snakes and Foxes: A game that is much loved by children until they mature enough to realize that it can never be won without breaking the rules. It is played with a board that has a web of lines with arrows indicating direction. There are ten discs inked with triangles to represent the foxes, and ten discs inked with wavy lines to represent the snakes. The game is begun by saying, "Courage to strengthen, fire to blind, music to dazzle, iron to bind," while describing a triangle with a wavy line through it with one's hand. Dice are rolled to determine moves for the players and the snakes and foxes. If a snake or fox lands on a player's piece, he is out of the game, and as long as the rules are followed, this always happens.

sɔɪhɪn: ðə kloʊsəs tʃɹænzleɪʃən fɹəm ði oʊl tʌŋ wəd bi "ə haɪɾ əmʌŋ loʊnəs," ðoʊ səm tʃɹænzleɪɾ ɪɾ əz minɪŋ "boʊθ skaɪ ən væli" əmʌŋ sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ pɑsəbɪləɾiz. sɔɪhɪn ɪz ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə hɝɛɾətɛɹi ʌpɝ sɝvəns. ðeɪ ɑɹ dækoʊvæl, pɹɑpɝɾi, jɛɾ ɑkjəpaɪ pəzɪʃənz ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl əθɔɹəɾi ən ɔfən paʊɝ. ivən ðə blʌd stɛp kɛɹfəli ɝaʊn sɔɪhɪn ə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, ən spik tə sɔɪhɪn ə ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf əz tə ikwəlz. si ɔlsoʊ blʌd, ðə;

so'jhin: The closest translation from the Old Tongue would be "a height among lowness," though some translate it as meaning "both sky and valley" among several other possibilities. So'jhin is the term applied by the Seanchan to hereditary upper servants. They are da'covale, property, yet occupy positions of considerable authority and often power. Even the Blood step carefully around so'jhin of the Imperial family, and speak to so'jhin of the Empress herself as to equals. See also Blood, the;

dækoʊvæl.

da'covale.

stænʒɹdbɛɹɝ: eɪ sintʃæn ɹæŋk ɪkwɪvələn tə bænɝmən.

Standardbearer: A Seanchan rank equivalent to Bannerman.

səksɛʃən: ɪn dʒɛnɝəl, wən wʌn haʊs səksidz ənʌðɝ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn. ɪn ændɝ, ðə tɝm ɪz waɪdli juz fəɹ ðə stʃɹʌɡəl fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn ðəɾ ɝoʊz əpɑn mɔɹdʒɹɛlənz dɛθ. tɪɡɹeɪnz dɪsəpɪɹəns hæd lɛf mæntʃɹ wɪθaʊɾ ə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, ən tu jɪɹz pæs bɪfɔɹ mɔɹɡeɪs, ʌv haʊs tʃɹəkənd, tʊk ðə θɹoʊn. aʊtsaɪɾ ʌv ændɝ, ðɪs kɑnflɪkt wɑz noʊn əz ðə θɝd wɔɹ ʌv ændɔɝən səksɛʃən.

Succession: In general, when one House succeeds another on the throne. In Andor, the term is widely used for the struggle for the throne that arose upon Mordrellen's death. Tigraine's disappearance had left Mantear without a Daughter-Heir, and two years passed before Morgase, of House Trakand, took the throne. Outside of Andor, this conflict was known as the Third War of Andoran Succession.

sɔɹd-kæptən: si læns-kæptən.

Sword-Captain: See Lance-Captain.

tæɹɑbən: ə neɪʃən ɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. wʌns ə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ neɪʃən, ə sɔɹs ə ɹʌɡz, daɪz ən ðə ɡɪld ʌv ɪluməneɪɾɝz' faɪɹwɝks əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz, tæɹɑbən əz fɔlən ɑn hɑɹd taɪmz. ɹæk baɪ ænɝki ən sɪvəl wɔɹ kəmpaʊndəd baɪ saɪməlteɪniəs wɔɹz əɡɛnst ɑɹæd dumən ən ðə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn, ɪt wɑz ɹaɪp fəɹ ðə pɪkɪŋ wən ðə sintʃæn ɝaɪvd. ɪts naʊ fɝmli ʌndɝ sintʃæn kəntʃɹoʊl, ðə tʃæptɝ haʊs ə ðə ɡɪld ʌv ɪluməneɪɾɝz əz bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ən ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz ðɛmsɛlvz əv bɪn meɪd dækoʊvæl. moʊs tæɹɑbənɝz əpɪɹ ɡɹeɪtfəl ðət ðə sintʃæn əv ɹɪstɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ, ən sɪns ðə sintʃæn əlaʊ ðɛm tə kəntɪnju lɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ laɪvz wɪð mɪnəməl ɪntɝfɪɹəns, ðeɪv noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə bɹɪŋ ɑn mɔɹ wɔɹfɛɹ baɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃeɪs ðə sintʃæn aʊt. ðəɹ ɑɹ, haʊɛvɝ, səm lɔɹdz ən soʊlʒɝz u ɹɪmeɪn aʊtsaɪd ðə sintʃæn sfɪɹ ʌv ɪnfluəns ən ɑɹ faɪɾɪŋ tə ɹikleɪm ðɛɹ lænd.

Tarabon: A nation on the Aryth Ocean. Once a great trading nation, a source of rugs, dyes and the Guild of Illuminators' fireworks among other things, Tarabon has fallen on hard times. Racked by anarchy and civil war compounded by simultaneous wars against Arad Doman and the Dragonsworn, it was ripe for the picking when the Seanchan arrived. It is now firmly under Seanchan control, the chapter house of the Guild of Illuminators has been destroyed and the Illuminators themselves have been made da'covale. Most Taraboners appear grateful that the Seanchan have restored order, and since the Seanchan allow them to continue living their lives with minimal interference, they have no desire to bring on more warfare by trying to chase the Seanchan out. There are, however, some lords and soldiers who remain outside the Seanchan sphere of influence and are fighting to reclaim their land.

θɔts əmʌŋ ðə ɹuənz: ən eɪntʃənt wɝk ə hɪstɝi.

Thoughts Among the Ruins: An ancient work of history.

weɪk ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, ðə: ə bʊk ʌv wɪtʃ lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn.

Wake of the Breaking, The: A book of which little is known.

weɪt, junəts ʌv: tɛn aʊnsəz ikwəlz wʌn paʊnd; tɛn paʊnz ikwəlz wʌn stoʊn; tɛn stoʊn ikwəlz wʌn hʌnʒɹədweɪt; tɛn

wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, ðə: ðə pɝsənəl bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ə ðə fɝst ə min, ən ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ə min. mɛmbɝz ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz wɛɹ ɹɛd-peɪntəd bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts ʃeɪp laɪk ɹɪm pɑts ðət kʌm daʊn tə ðə neɪp ə ðə nɛks ɪn ðə bæk, ən kæɹi ɹɛd- stʃɹimɝd lænsɪz. ɔfəsɝz əv wɪŋz wɝkt ɑn ðə saɪdz ə ðɛɹ hɛlməts, ən ɹæŋk ɪz dɪnoʊɾəd baɪ slɛndɝ plumz.

Winged Guards, the: The personal bodyguards of the First of Mayene, and the elite military formation of Mayene. Members of the Winged Guards wear red-painted breastplates and helmets shaped like rimmed pots that come down to the nape of the necks in the back, and carry red- streamered lances. Officers have wings worked on the sides of their helmets, and rank is denoted by slender plumes.

əbaʊt ði ɔθɝz ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən wɑz bɔɹn ɪn naɪntinfɔɹɾieɪt ɪn tʃɑɹlstən, saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə. hi tɔt hɪmsɛlf tə ɹid wən i wɑz fɔɹ wɪð ði ɪnsɪdɛntəl eɪɾ ʌv ə twɛlv-jɪɹz-oʊldɝ bɹʌðɝ, ən wɑz tæklɪŋ mɑɹk tweɪn ən dʒulz vɝn baɪ faɪv. hi wɑz ə ɡɹædʒəwəɾ ə ðə sɪɾədɛl, ðə mɪlətɛɹi kɑlɪdʒ ə saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə, wɪð ə dɪɡɹi ɪn fɪzɪks. hi sɝv tu tʊɹz ɪn viɛtnɑm wɪð ðə juɛs. ɑɹmi; əmʌŋ ɪz dɛkɝeɪʃənz ɑɹ ðə dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt flaɪɪŋ kɹɔs wɪð bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ðə bɹɑnz stɑɹ wɪð "vi" ən bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ən tu viɛtnɑmis ɡæləntʃɹi kɹɔsɪz wɪð pɑm. ə hɪstɝi bʌf, hi ɔlsoʊ ɹoʊt dæns ən θiəɾɝ kɹɪɾɪsɪzəm. hi ɛndʒɔɪd ði aʊtdɔɹ spɔɹts ə hʌntɪŋ, fɪʃɪŋ, ən seɪlɪŋ, ən ði ɪndɔɹ spɔɹts ə poʊkɝ, tʃɛs, pul, ən paɪp kəlɛktɪŋ. hi bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn naɪntinsɛvəntisɛvən ən kəntɪnjuɾ əntɪl ɪz dɛθ ɑn sɛptɛmbɝ sɪkstinθ, tuθaʊzənsɛvən.

About the Authors Robert Jordan was born in 1948 in Charleston, South Carolina. He taught himself to read when he was four with the incidental aid of a twelve-years-older brother, and was tackling Mark Twain and Jules Verne by five. He was a graduate of The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina, with a degree in physics. He served two tours in Vietnam with the U.S. Army; among his decorations are the Distinguished Flying Cross with bronze oak leaf cluster, the Bronze Star with "V" and bronze oak leaf cluster, and two Vietnamese Gallantry Crosses with Palm. A history buff, he also wrote dance and theater criticism. He enjoyed the outdoor sports of hunting, fishing, and sailing, and the indoor sports of poker, chess, pool, and pipe collecting. He began writing in 1977 and continued until his death on September 16, 2007.

bɹændən sændɝsən wɑz bɔɹn ɪn naɪntinsɛvəntifaɪv ɪn lɪŋkən, nəbɹæskə. æftɝ ə səmɛstɝ əz ə baɪətʃəm meɪdʒɝ, bɹændən keɪm tə hɪz sɛnsɪz ən ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɹaɪɾɪŋ əz ɪz tʃɹu voʊkeɪʃən. hi swɪtʃt tə ɪŋɡlɪʃ, ɡɹædʒəweɪɾɪŋ fɹəm bɹɪɡəm jʌŋ junəvɝsəɾi, ðən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fəɹ ə mæstɝz ɪn kɹieɪɾɪv ɹaɪɾɪŋ. dʊɹɪŋ ðɪs taɪm bɹændən ɹoʊt θɝtin nɑvəlz, faɪnəli pʌblɪʃɪŋ ɪz sɪksθ, ilæntʃɹɪs, ɪn tuθaʊzənfaɪv. hiz sɪns ɹilis bʊks fəɹ boʊθ ədʌls ən jʌŋ ɹiɾɝz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə mɪsbɹn tʃɹɪlədʒi, wɔɹbɹeɪkɝ, ən ði ɑlkætʃɹɑz sɪɹiz. hi lɪvz wɪð ɪz waɪf ən tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn jutɔ, wɛɹ i ɔfən pleɪz mædʒɪk: ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ, ɹɛɡjəlɝli its mæk-ænd-tʃiz, ən əkeɪʒənəli titʃəz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ət bju. faɪn mɔɹ ət wwwbɹændɑnsændɝsənkɑm.

Brandon Sanderson was born in 1975 in Lincoln, Nebraska. After a semester as a biochem major, Brandon came to his senses and recognized writing as his true vocation. He switched to English, graduating from Brigham Young University, then returning for a master's in creative writing. During this time Brandon wrote thirteen novels, finally publishing his sixth, Elantris, in 2005. He has since released books for both adults and young readers, including the Mistborn trilogy, Warbreaker, and the Alcatraz series. He lives with his wife and children in Utah, where he often plays Magic: The Gathering, regularly eats mac-and-cheese, and occasionally teaches writing at BYU. Find more at www.brandonsanderson.com.
